"nɑɾ ɔl hɛɹən-mɑɹk bleɪdz ɑɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝk. fju mɛn hændəl ə sɔɹd wɪð ðə skɪl tə bi neɪm bleɪdmæstɝ ən bi əwɔɹɾəd ə hɛɹən-mɑɹk bleɪd, bʌɾ ivən soʊ, nɑɾ ɪnʌf ɛɛs sədaɪ bleɪdz ɹɪmeɪn fəɹ mɔɹ ðən ə hændfʊl tə hæv wʌn. moʊs kʌm fɹəm mæstɝ bleɪdɛsmɪθs; ðə faɪnəst stil mɛn kən meɪk, jɛt stɪl ɹɔt baɪ ə mænz hænz. bʌt ðət wʌn, ʃifɝɾɝ . . . ðət wʌn kəd tɛl ə teɪl ə θɹi θaʊzən jɪɹz ən mɔɹ."

"Not all heron-mark blades are Aes Sedai work. Few men handle a sword with the skill to be named blademaster and be awarded a heron-mark blade, but even so, not enough Aes Sedai blades remain for more than a handful to have one. Most come from master bladesmiths; the finest steel men can make, yet still wrought by a man's hands. But that one, sheepherder . . . that one could tell a tale of three thousand years and more."

"aɪ kænt ɡɛɾ əweɪ fɹəm ðɛm," ɹænd sɛd, "kæn aɪ?" hi bæləns ðə sɔɹɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm ɑn skæbɝd pɔɪnt; ɪt lʊk noʊ dɪfɹən ðən ɪt hæd bɪfɔɹ i nu. "ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝk." bʌt tæm ɡeɪv ɪt tə mi. maɪ fɑðɝ ɡeɪv ɪt tə mi. hi ɹəfjuz tə θɪŋk ə haʊ ə tu ɹɪvɝz ʃɛpɝd hæd kʌm baɪ ə hɛɹən-mɑɹk bleɪd. ðəɹ wɝ deɪnʒɝəs kɝəns ɪn sətʃ θɔts, dips i dɪd nɑt wɑnə ɪksplɔɹ.

"I can't get away from them," Rand said, "can I?" He balanced the sword in front of him on scabbard point; it looked no different than it had before he knew. "Aes Sedai work." But Tam gave it to me. My father gave it to me. He refused to think of how a Two Rivers shepherd had come by a heron-mark blade. There were dangerous currents in such thoughts, deeps he did not want to explore.

"du jə ɹɪli wɑnə ɡɛɾ əweɪ, ʃifɝɾɝ? əl æsk əɡɛn. waɪ ɑɹ jə nɑt ɡɔn, ðɛn? ðə sɔɹd? ɪn faɪv jɪɹz aɪ kəd meɪk jə wɝði ʌv ɪt, meɪk jə ə bleɪdmæstɝ. juv kwɪk ɹɪsts, ɡʊd bæləns, ən jə doʊn meɪk ðə seɪm mɪsteɪk twaɪs. bʌɾ aɪ də nɑɾ əv faɪv jɪɹz tə ɡɪv oʊvɝ tə titʃɪŋ ju, ən jə də nɑɾ əv faɪv jɪɹz fəɹ lɝnɪŋ. juv nɑɾ ivən wʌn jɪɹ, ən jə noʊ ɪt. əz ɪɾ ɪz, jəl nɑt stæb jɝsɛlf ɪn ðə fʊt. jə hoʊl jɝsɛlf əz ɪf ðə sɔɹd bɪlɔŋz ət jəɹ weɪst, ʃifɝɾɝ, ən moʊs vɪlədʒ bʊliz wɪl sɛns ɪt. bʌt juv hæd ðət mʌtʃ ɔlmoʊst sɪns ðə deɪ jə pʊɾ ɪɾ ɑn. soʊ waɪ ɑɹ jə stɪl hɪɹ?"

"Do you really want to get away, sheepherder? I'll ask again. Why are you not gone, then? The sword? In five years I could make you worthy of it, make you a blademaster. You have quick wrists, good balance, and you don't make the same mistake twice. But I do not have five years to give over to teaching you, and you do not have five years for learning. You have not even one year, and you know it. As it is, you will not stab yourself in the foot. You hold yourself as if the sword belongs at your waist, sheepherder, and most village bullies will sense it. But you've had that much almost since the day you put it on. So why are you still here?"

"mæɾ ən pɛɹɪn ɑɹ stɪl hɪɹ," ɹænd mʌmbəld. "aɪ doʊnt wɑnə liv bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ du. aɪ woʊn ɛvɝ - aɪ maɪt nɑt si ðɛm əɡɛn fəɹ - fəɹ jɪɹz, meɪbi." hɪz hɛd dʒɹɑp bæk əɡɛns ðə wɔl. "blʌɾ ən æʃəz! ət lis ðeɪ dʒʌs θɪŋk aɪm kɹeɪzi nɑt tə ɡoʊ hoʊm wɪð ðɛm. hæf ðə taɪm nɪneɪiv lʊks ət mi laɪk aɪm sɪks jɪɹz oʊld ən aɪv skɪn maɪ ni, ən ʃiz gɑnə meɪk ɪt bɛɾɝ; ði ʌðɝ hæf ʃi lʊks laɪk ʃiz siɪŋ ə stʃɹeɪnʒɝ. wʌn ʃi maɪɾ əfɛn ɪf ʃi lʊks tu kloʊsli, ət ðæt. ʃiz ə wɪzdəm, ən bɪsaɪdz ðæt, aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ʃiz ɛvɝ bɪn əfɹeɪɾ ʌv ɛniθɪŋ, bʌt ʃi. . . ." hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "æn ɛɡwin. bɝn mi! ʃi noʊz waɪ aɪ hæv tə ɡoʊ, bʌɾ ɛvɹi taɪm aɪ mɛnʃən ɪt ʃi lʊks ət mi, ən aɪ nɑɾ ʌp ɪnsaɪɾ ænd. . . ." hi kloʊzd ɪz aɪz, pɹɛsɪŋ ðə sɔɹd hɪlt əɡɛnst ɪz fɔɹhɛɾ əz ɪf i kəd pɹɛs wʌɾ i wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ aʊɾ ʌv ɛɡzɪstəns. "aɪ wɪʃ. . . . aɪ wɪʃ. . . ."

"Mat and Perrin are still here," Rand mumbled. "I don't want to leave before they do. I won't ever - I might not see them again for - for years, maybe." His head dropped back against the wall. "Blood and ashes! At least they just think I'm crazy not to go home with them. Half the time Nynaeve looks at me like I'm six years old and I've skinned my knee, and she's going to make it better; the other half she looks like she's seeing a stranger. One she might offend if she looks too closely, at that. She's a Wisdom, and besides that, I don't think she's ever been afraid of anything, but she. . . ." He shook his head. "And Egwene. Burn me! She knows why I have to go, but every time I mention it she looks at me, and I knot up inside and. . . ." He closed his eyes, pressing the sword hilt against his forehead as if he could press what he was thinking out of existence. "I wish. . . . I wish. . . ."

"ju wɪʃ ɛvɹiθɪŋ kəd bi ðə weɪ ɪt wɑz, ʃifɝɾɝ? əɹ jə wɪʃ ðə ɡɝl wəd ɡoʊ wɪð jə ɪnstɛɾ ə tə tɑɹ vəlɑn? jə θɪŋk ʃɪl ɡɪv ʌp bɪkʌmɪŋ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ fəɹ ə laɪf ʌv wɑndɝɪŋ? wɪð ju? ɪf jə pʊɾ ɪt tə hɝ ɪn ðə ɹaɪt weɪ, ʃi maɪt. lʌv ɪz ən ɑd θɪŋ." læn saʊndəd sʌɾənli wɪɹi. "æz ɑɾ ə θɪŋ əz ðəɹ ɪz."

"You wish everything could be the way it was, sheepherder? Or you wish the girl would go with you instead of to Tar Valon? You think she'll give up becoming an Aes Sedai for a life of wandering? With you? If you put it to her in the right way, she might. Love is an odd thing." Lan sounded suddenly weary. "As odd a thing as there is."

"noʊ." ɪt wɑz wʌɾ i hæd bɪn wɪʃɪŋ, ðət ʃi wəd wɑnə ɡoʊ wɪð hɪm. hi oʊpən ɪz aɪz ən skwɛɹɾ ɪz bæk ən meɪɾ ɪz vɔɪs fɝm. "noʊ, aɪ wʊdn lɛɾ əɹ kʌm wɪð mi ɪf ʃi dɪɾ æsk." hi kəd nɑt də ðət tə hɝ. bʌt laɪt, wʊdn ɪt bi swit, dʒʌs fəɹ ə mɪnət, ɪf ʃi sɛd ʃi wɑntəd tə? "ʃi ɡɛts mjuli stʌbɝn ɪf ʃi θɪŋks aɪm tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə tɛl əɹ wʌt tə du, bʌɾ aɪ kən stɪl pɹətɛkt əɹ fɹəm ðæt." hi wɪʃt ʃi wɝ bæk hoʊm ɪn ɛmənz fild, bʌɾ ɔl hoʊp ə ðət hæd ɡɔn ðə deɪ mɔɪɹeɪn keɪm tə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. "ivən ɪf ɪt minz ʃi dʌz bɪkʌm ən ɛɛs sədaɪ!" ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz aɪ kɑt lænz ɹeɪzd aɪbɹaʊ, ən i flʌʃt.

"No." It was what he had been wishing, that she would want to go with him. He opened his eyes and squared his back and made his voice firm. "No, I wouldn't let her come with me if she did ask." He could not do that to her. But Light, wouldn't it be sweet, just for a minute, if she said she wanted to? "She gets muley stubborn if she thinks I'm trying to tell her what to do, but I can still protect her from that." He wished she were back home in Emond's Field, but all hope of that had gone the day Moiraine came to the Two Rivers. "Even if it means she does become an Aes Sedai!" The corner of his eye caught Lan's raised eyebrow, and he flushed.

"æn ðəɾ ɪz ɔl ðə ɹizən? jə wɑnə spɛn əz mʌtʃ taɪm əz jə kən wɪð jəɹ fɹɛnz fɹəm hoʊm bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ ɡoʊ? ðæts waɪ jəɹ dʒɹæɡɪŋ jəɹ fit? jə noʊ wʌts snɪfɪŋ ət jəɹ hilz."

"And that is all the reason? You want to spend as much time as you can with your friends from home before they go? That's why you're dragging your feet? You know what's sniffing at your heels."

ɹænd sɝdʒd æŋɡɹəli tə hɪz fit. "ɔl ɹaɪt, ɪts mɔɪɹeɪn! aɪ wʊdn ivən bi hɪɹ ɪf nɑt fəɹ hɝ, ən ʃi woʊn əz mʌtʃ əz tɔk tə mi."

Rand surged angrily to his feet. "All right, it's Moiraine! I wouldn't even be here if not for her, and she won't as much as talk to me."

"jud bi dɛɾ ɪf nɑt fəɹ hɝ, ʃifɝɾɝ," læn sɛd flætli, bʌt ɹænd ɹʌʃt ɑn.

"You'd be dead if not for her, sheepherder," Lan said flatly, but Rand rushed on.

"ʃi tɛlz mi . . . tɛlz mi hɔɹəbəl θɪŋz əbaʊt maɪsɛlf" - hɪz nʌkəlz waɪɾənd ɑn ðə sɔɹd. ðəɾ aɪm gɑnə ɡoʊ mæɾ ən daɪ! - "æn ðən sʌɾənli ʃi woʊn ivən seɪ tu wɝdz tə mi. ʃi æks əz ɪf ɪm noʊ dɪfɹən ðən ðə deɪ ʃi faʊn mi, ən ðət smɛlz ɹɔŋ, tu."

"She tells me . . . tells me horrible things about myself" - his knuckles whitened on the sword. That I'm going to go mad and die! - "and then suddenly she won't even say two words to me. She acts as if I'm no different than the day she found me, and that smells wrong, too."

"ju wɑn əɹ tə tʃɹit jə laɪk wʌt jə ɑɹ?"

"You want her to treat you like what you are?"

"noʊ! aɪ doʊn min ðæt. bɝn mi, aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌɾ aɪ min hæf ðə taɪm. aɪ doʊnt wɑn ðæt, ən aɪm skɛɹɾ ə ði ʌðɝ. naʊ ʃiz ɡɔn ɔf sʌmwɛɹ, vænɪʃt . . ."

"No! I don't mean that. Burn me, I don't know what I mean half the time. I don't want that, and I'm scared of the other. Now she's gone off somewhere, vanished . . ."

"aɪ toʊl jə ʃi nidz tə bi əloʊn səmtaɪmz. ɪɾ ɪzən fəɹ ju, əɹ ɛniwʌn ɛls, tə kwɛstʃən əɹ ækʃənz."

"I told you she needs to be alone sometimes. It isn't for you, or anyone else, to question her actions."

". . . wɪθaʊt tɛlɪŋ ɛnibəɾi wɛɹ ʃi wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ, əɹ wən ʃid bi bæk, əɹ ivən ɪf ʃi wəd bi bæk. ʃiz tə bi eɪbəl tə tɛl mi sʌmθɪŋ tə hɛlp mi, læn. sʌmθɪŋ. ʃiz tə. ɪf ʃi ɛvɝ kʌmz bæk."

". . . without telling anybody where she was going, or when she'd be back, or even if she would be back. She has to be able to tell me something to help me, Lan. Something. She has to. If she ever comes back."

"ʃiz bæk, ʃifɝɾɝ. læs naɪt. bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk ʃiz toʊl jə ɔl ʃi kæn. bi sæɾəsfaɪd. juv lɝnd wʌt jə kən fɹəm hɝ." wɪð ə ʃeɪk ə hɪz hɛd, lænz vɔɪs bɪkeɪm bɹɪsk. "ju sɝɾənli ɑɹən lɝnɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ stændɪŋ ðɛɹ. taɪm fəɹ ə lɪɾəl bæləns wɝk. ɡoʊ θɹu pɑɹɾɪŋ ðə sɪlk, bɪɡɪnɪŋ fɹəm hɛɹən weɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə ɹʌʃəz. ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðət ðət hɛɹən fɔɹm ɪz oʊnli fəɹ pɹæktəsɪŋ bæləns. ɛniwɛɹ bʌt duɪŋ fɔɹmz, ɪt livz jə waɪɾ oʊpən; jə kən stʃɹaɪk hoʊm fɹəm ɪt, ɪf jə weɪt fəɹ ði ʌðɝ mæn tə muv fɝst, bʌt jəl nɛvɝ əvɔɪɾ ɪz bleɪd."

"She's back, sheepherder. Last night. But I think she has told you all she can. Be satisfied. You've learned what you can from her." With a shake of his head, Lan's voice became brisk. "You certainly aren't learning anything standing there. Time for a little balance work. Go through Parting the Silk, beginning from Heron Wading in the Rushes. Remember that that Heron form is only for practicing balance. Anywhere but doing forms, it leaves you wide open; you can strike home from it, if you wait for the other man to move first, but you'll never avoid his blade."

"ʃi hæz tə bi eɪbəl tə tɛl mi sʌmθɪŋ, læn. ðət waɪnd. ɪt wɑznt nætʃɹəl, ən aɪ doʊn kɛɹ haʊ kloʊs tə ðə blaɪt wi ɑɹ."

"She has to be able to tell me something, Lan. That wind. It wasn't natural, and I don't care how close to the Blight we are."

"hɛɹən weɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə ɹʌʃəz, ʃifɝɾɝ. ən maɪn jəɹ ɹɪsts."

"Heron Wading in the Rushes, sheepherder. And mind your wrists."

fɹəm ðə saʊθ keɪm ə feɪn pil ə tʃɹʌmpəts, ə ɹoʊlɪŋ fænfɛɹ sloʊli ɡɹoʊɪŋ laʊɾɝ, əkʌmpənid baɪ ðə stɛɾi θɹəm-θɹəm-θɹəm-θɹəm ə dʒɹʌmz. fəɹ ə moʊmən ɹænd ən læn stɛɹɾ əɾ itʃ ʌðɝ, ðən ðə dʒɹʌmz dʒɹu ðɛm tə ðə taʊɝ wɔl tə stɛɹ saʊθwɝd.

From the south came a faint peal of trumpets, a rolling fanfare slowly growing louder, accompanied by the steady thrum-thrum-THRUM-thrum of drums. For a moment Rand and Lan stared at each other, then the drums drew them to the tower wall to stare southward.

ðə sɪɾi stʊɾ ɑn haɪ hɪlz, ðə læn ɝaʊn ðə sɪɾi wɔlz klɪɹd tə æŋkəl haɪt fəɹ ə fʊl maɪl ɪn ɔl dɝɛkʃənz, ən ðə kip kʌvɝd ðə haɪəs hɪl ʌv ɔl. fɹəm ðə taʊɝ tɑp, ɹænd hæɾ ə klɪɹ vju əkɹɔs ðə tʃɪmniz ən ɹufs tə ðə fɔɹəst. ðə dʒɹʌmɝz əpɪɹd fɝs fɹəm ðə tʃɹiz, ə dʌzən ə ðɛm, dʒɹʌmz lɪftɪŋ əz ðeɪ stɛp tə ðɛɹ oʊn bit, mæləts wɝlɪŋ. nɛks keɪm tʃɹʌmpəɾɝz, lɔŋ, ʃaɪnɪŋ hɔɹnz ɹeɪzd, stɪl kɔlɪŋ ðə flɝɪʃ. ət ðət dɪstəns ɹænd kəd nɑt meɪk aʊt ðə hjudʒ, skwɛɹ bænɝ wɪpɪŋ ɪn ðə wɪn bɪhaɪn ðɛm. læn ɡɹʌntɪd, ðoʊ; ðə wɔɹɾɝ hæɾ aɪz laɪk ə snoʊ iɡəl.

The city stood on high hills, the land around the city walls cleared to ankle height for a full mile in all directions, and the keep covered the highest hill of all. From the tower top, Rand had a clear view across the chimneys and roofs to the forest. The drummers appeared first from the trees, a dozen of them, drums lifting as they stepped to their own beat, mallets whirling. Next came trumpeters, long, shining horns raised, still calling the flourish. At that distance Rand could not make out the huge, square banner whipping in the wind behind them. Lan grunted, though; the Warder had eyes like a snow eagle.

ɹænd ɡlænst ət hɪm, bʌt ðə wɔɹɾɝ sɛd nʌθɪŋ, hɪz aɪz ɪntɛn ɑn ðə kɑləm ɪmɝdʒɪŋ fɹəm ðə fɔɹəst. maʊntəd mɛn ɪn ɑɹmɝ ɹoʊɾ aʊɾ ə ðə tʃɹiz, ən wɪmən əhɔɹsbæk, tu. ðən ə pɑlɑnkwɪn bɔɹn baɪ hɔɹsəz, wʌn bɪfɔɹ ən wʌn bɪhaɪnd, ɪts kɝɾənz daʊn, ən mɔɹ mɛn ɑn hɔɹsbæk. ɹæŋks ə mɛn əfʊt, paɪks ɹaɪzɪŋ əbʌv əm laɪk ə bɹɪsəl ə lɔŋ θɔɹnz, ən ɑɹtʃɝz wɪð ðɛɹ baʊz hɛl slæntəɾ əkɹɔs ðɛɹ tʃɛsts, ɔl stɛpɪŋ tə ðə dʒɹʌmz. ðə tʃɹʌmpəts kɹaɪɾ əɡɛn. laɪk ə sɪŋɪŋ sɝpən ðə kɑləm waʊn ɪts weɪ təwɔɹd fæl dæɹə.

Rand glanced at him, but the Warder said nothing, his eyes intent on the column emerging from the forest. Mounted men in armor rode out of the trees, and women ahorseback, too. Then a palanquin borne by horses, one before and one behind, its curtains down, and more men on horseback. Ranks of men afoot, pikes rising above them like a bristle of long thorns, and archers with their bows held slanted across their chests, all stepping to the drums. The trumpets cried again. Like a singing serpent the column wound its way toward Fal Dara.

ðə wɪn flæp ðə bænɝ, tɔlɝ ðən ə mæn, stʃɹeɪɾ aʊt tə wʌn saɪd. əz bɪɡ əz ɪt wɑz, ɪt wɑz kloʊs ɪnʌf naʊ fəɹ ɹænd tə si klɪɹli. ə swɝl ə kʌlɝz ðət mɛnt nʌθɪŋ tə hɪm, bʌɾ ət ðə hɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt, ə ʃeɪp laɪk ə pjʊɹ waɪt tɪɹdʒɹɑp. hɪz bɹɛθ fɹoʊz ɪn ɪz θɹoʊt. ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn.

The wind flapped the banner, taller than a man, straight out to one side. As big as it was, it was close enough now for Rand to see clearly. A swirl of colors that meant nothing to him, but at the heart of it, a shape like a pure white teardrop. His breath froze in his throat. The Flame of Tar Valon.

"ɪŋtʃɹz wɪð ðɛm." læn saʊndəɾ əz ɪf ɪz θɔts wɝ ɛlswɛɹ. "bæk fɹəm ɪz hʌntɪŋ ət læst. bɪn ɡɔn lɔŋ ɪnʌf. aɪ wʌndɝ ɪf i hæɾ ɛni lʌk?"

"Ingtar's with them." Lan sounded as if his thoughts were elsewhere. "Back from his hunting at last. Been gone long enough. I wonder if he had any luck?"

"ɛɛs sədaɪ," ɹænd wɪspɝd wən i faɪnəli kʊd. ɔl ðoʊz wɪmən aʊt ðɛɹ. . . . mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ, jɛs, bʌɾ i hæd tʃɹævəld wɪð hɝ, ən ɪf i dɪd nɑɾ ɪntaɪɝli tʃɹʌs hɝ, ət list i nu hɝ. əɹ θɔɾ i dɪd. bʌt ʃi wɑz oʊnli wʌn. soʊ mɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ təɡɛðɝ, ən kʌmɪŋ laɪk ðɪs, wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɛls əɡɛn. hi klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊt; wən i spoʊk, hɪz vɔɪs ɡɹeɪɾɪd. "waɪ soʊ mɛni, læn? waɪ ɛni əɾ ɔl? ən wɪð dʒɹʌmz ən tʃɹʌmpəts ən ə bænɝ tə ənaʊns ðɛm."

"Aes Sedai," Rand whispered when he finally could. All those women out there. . . . Moiraine was Aes Sedai, yes, but he had traveled with her, and if he did not entirely trust her, at least he knew her. Or thought he did. But she was only one. So many Aes Sedai together, and coming like this, was something else again. He cleared his throat; when he spoke, his voice grated. "Why so many, Lan? Why any at all? And with drums and trumpets and a banner to announce them."

ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ ɹɪspɛktɪɾ ɪn ʃaɪnɝ, ət lis baɪ moʊs pipəl, ən ðə ɹɛst ɹɪspɛkfəli fɪɹd ðɛm, bʌt ɹænd hæd bɪn ɪn pleɪsəz wɛɹ ɪt wɑz dɪfɹənt, wɛɹ ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli ðə fɪɹ, ən ɔfən heɪt. wɛɹ i hæd ɡɹoʊn ʌp, səm mɛn, ət list, spoʊk ʌv "tɑɹ vəlɑn wɪtʃəz" əz ðeɪ wəd spik ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn. hi tʃɹaɪd tə kaʊn ðə wɪmən, bʌt ðeɪ kɛp noʊ ɹæŋks əɹ ɔɹɾɝ, muvɪŋ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz ɝaʊn tə kənvɝs wɪð wʌn ənʌðɝ əɹ wɪð huɛvɝ wɑz ɪn ðə pɑlɑnkwɪn. ɡus bʌmps kʌvɝd hɪm. hi hæd tʃɹævəld wɪð mɔɪɹeɪn, ən mɛɾ ənʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən i hæd bɪɡʌn tə θɪŋk ə hɪmsɛlf əz wɝldli. noʊbɑdi ɛvɝ lɛf ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, əɹ ɔlmoʊs noʊbɑdi, bʌɾ i hæd. hi hæd sin θɪŋz noʊ wʌn bæk ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz hæɾ ɛvɝ leɪɾ aɪz ɑn, dʌn θɪŋz ðeɪ hæɾ oʊnli dʒɹimd ʌv, ɪf ðeɪ hæd dʒɹim soʊ fɑɹ. hi hæd sin ə kwin ən mɛt ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ʌv ændɝ, feɪst ə mɹdʒɹɑl ən tʃɹævəl ðə weɪz, ən nʌn ʌv ɪt hæd pɹipɛɹɾ ɪm fəɹ ðɪs moʊmənt.

Aes Sedai were respected in Shienar, at least by most people, and the rest respectfully feared them, but Rand had been in places where it was different, where there was only the fear, and often hate. Where he had grown up, some men, at least, spoke of "Tar Valon witches" as they would speak of the Dark One. He tried to count the women, but they kept no ranks or order, moving their horses around to converse with one another or with whoever was in the palanquin. Goose bumps covered him. He had traveled with Moiraine, and met another Aes Sedai, and he had begun to think of himself as worldly. Nobody ever left the Two Rivers, or almost nobody, but he had. He had seen things no one back in the Two Rivers had ever laid eyes on, done things they had only dreamed of, if they had dreamed so far. He had seen a queen and met the Daughter-Heir of Andor, faced a Myrddraal and traveled the Ways, and none of it had prepared him for this moment.

"waɪ soʊ mɛni?" hi wɪspɝɾ əɡɛn.

"Why so many?" he whispered again.

"ði æmɪɝlɪn sits kʌm ɪn pɝsən." læn lʊkt ət hɪm, hɪz ɪkspɹɛʃən əz hɑɹɾ ən ənɹiɾəbəl əz ə ɹɑk. "jɔɹ lɛsənz ɑɹ dʌn, ʃifɝɾɝ." hi pɔz ðɛn, ən ɹænd ɔlmoʊs θɔt ðəɹ wɑz sɪmpəθi ɑn ɪz feɪs. ðət kəd nɑt bi, ʌv kɔɹs. "bɛɾɝ fəɹ jə ɪf jə wɝ ə wik ɡɔn." wɪð ðət ðə wɔɹɾɝ snætʃt ʌp ɪz ʃɝɾ ən dɪsəpɪɹd daʊn ðə læɾɝ ɪndə ðə taʊɝ.

"The Amyrlin Seat's come in person." Lan looked at him, his expression as hard and unreadable as a rock. "Your lessons are done, sheepherder." He paused then, and Rand almost thought there was sympathy on his face. That could not be, of course. "Better for you if you were a week gone." With that the Warder snatched up his shirt and disappeared down the ladder into the tower.

ɹænd wɝkt ɪz maʊθ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡɛɾ ə lɪɾəl mɔɪstʃɝ. hi stɛɹɾ ət ðə kɑləm əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ fæl dæɹə əz ɪf ɪt ɹɪli wɝ ə sneɪk, ə dɛdli vaɪpɝ. ðə dʒɹʌmz ən tʃɹʌmpəts sæŋ, laʊɾ ɪn ɪz ɪɹz. ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, hu ɔɹɾɝd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ʃiz kʌm kəz ə mi. hi kəd θɪŋk ə noʊ ʌðɝ ɹizən.

Rand worked his mouth, trying to get a little moisture. He stared at the column approaching Fal Dara as if it really were a snake, a deadly viper. The drums and trumpets sang, loud in his ears. The Amyrlin Seat, who ordered the Aes Sedai. She's come because of me. He could think of no other reason.

ðeɪ nu θɪŋz, hæd nɑlədʒ ðət kəd hɛlp hɪm, hi wɑz ʃʊɹ. ən i dɪd nɑt dɛɹ æsk ɛni ʌv ðɛm. hi wɑz əfɹeɪd ðeɪ hæd kʌm tə dʒɛntəl hɪm. ən əfɹeɪd ðeɪ hævənt, tu, hi ədmɪɾəd ɹɪlʌktənli. laɪt, aɪ doʊnt noʊ wɪtʃ skɛɹz mi mɔɹ.

They knew things, had knowledge that could help him, he was sure. And he did not dare ask any of them. He was afraid they had come to gentle him. And afraid they haven't, too, he admitted reluctantly. Light, I don't know which scares me more.

"aɪ dɪdn min tə tʃænəl ðə paʊɝ," hi wɪspɝd. "ɪt wɑz ən æksəɾənt! laɪt, aɪ doʊnt wɑn ɛniθɪŋ tə də wɪð ɪt. aɪ swɛɹ əl nɛvɝ tʌtʃ ɪɾ əɡɛn! aɪ swɛɹ ɪt!"

"I didn't mean to channel the Power," he whispered. "It was an accident! Light, I don't want anything to do with it. I swear I'll never touch it again! I swear it!"

wɪð ə stɑɹt, hi ɹilaɪz ðət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ pɑɹɾi wɑz ɛntɝɪŋ ðə sɪɾi ɡeɪts. ðə wɪn swɝld ʌp fɪɹsli, tʃɪlɪŋ ɪz swɛt laɪk dʒɹɑpləts ʌv aɪs, meɪkɪŋ ðə tʃɹʌmpəts saʊn laɪk slaɪ læftɝ; hi θɔɾ i kəd smɛl ən oʊpənd ɡɹeɪv, stʃɹɔŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ. maɪ ɡɹeɪv, ɪf aɪ kip stændɪŋ hɪɹ.

With a start, he realized that the Aes Sedai party was entering the city gates. The wind swirled up fiercely, chilling his sweat like droplets of ice, making the trumpets sound like sly laughter; he thought he could smell an opened grave, strong in the air. My grave, if I keep standing here.

ɡɹæbɪŋ ɪz ʃɝt, hi skɹæmbəl daʊn ðə læɾɝ ən bɪɡæn tə ɹʌn.

Grabbing his shirt, he scrambled down the ladder and began to run.


tʃæptɝ tu


CHAPTER 2

ðə wɛlkəm


The Welcome

ðə hɔlz ə fæl dæɹə kip, ðɛɹ smuð stoʊn wɔlz spɑɹsli dɛkɝeɪɾəd wɪð ɛlɪɡənli sɪmpəl tæpəstʃɹiz ən peɪntəd skɹinz, bʌsəld wɪð nuz ə ði æmɪɝlɪn sits ɪmənən ɝaɪvəl. sɝvəns ɪn blæk-ænd-ɡoʊl dɑɹɾɪd əbaʊt ðɛɹ tæsks, ɹʌnɪŋ tə pɹipɛɹ ɹumz əɹ kæɹi ɔɹɾɝz tə ðə kɪtʃənz, moʊnɪŋ ðət ðeɪ kəd nɑɾ əv ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɹɛɾi fəɹ soʊ ɡɹeɪɾ ə pɝsənɑdʒ wən ðeɪ hæd hæd noʊ wɔɹnɪŋ. dɑɹk-aɪd wɔɹiɝz, ðɛɹ hɛdz ʃeɪvən ɪksɛp fəɹ ə tɑpnɑt baʊnd wɪð ə lɛðɝ kɔɹd, dɪd nɑt ɹʌn, bʌt heɪs fɪl ðɛɹ stɛps ən ðɛɹ feɪsəz ʃoʊn wɪð ən ɪksaɪtmənt nɔɹməli ɹɪzɝv fəɹ bæɾəl. səm ə ðə mɛn spoʊk əz ɹænd hɝid pæst.

The halls of Fal Dara keep, their smooth stone walls sparsely decorated with elegantly simple tapestries and painted screens, bustled with news of the Amyrlin Seat's imminent arrival. Servants in black-and-gold darted about their tasks, running to prepare rooms or carry orders to the kitchens, moaning that they could not have everything ready for so great a personage when they had had no warning. Dark-eyed warriors, their heads shaven except for a topknot bound with a leather cord, did not run, but haste filled their steps and their faces shone with an excitement normally reserved for battle. Some of the men spoke as Rand hurried past.

"ɑ, ðəɹ jə ɑɹ, ɹænd ælθɹ. pis feɪvɝ jəɹ sɔɹd. ɑn jəɹ weɪ tə klin ʌp? jəl wɑnə lʊk jəɹ bɛst wən jə ɑɹ pɹizɛntəd tə ði æmɪɝlɪn sit. ʃɪl wɑnə si jə ən jəɹ tu fɹɛnz əz wɛl əz ðə wɪmən, jə kən kaʊn ɑn ɪt."

"Ah, there you are, Rand al'Thor. Peace favor your sword. On your way to clean up? You'll want to look your best when you are presented to the Amyrlin Seat. She'll want to see you and your two friends as well as the women, you can count on it."

hi tʃɹɑɾəd təwɔɹd ðə bɹɔd stɛɹz, waɪɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ twɛnti mɛn əbɹɛst, ðət lɛɾ ʌp tə ðə mɛnz əpɑɹtməns.

He trotted toward the broad stairs, wide enough for twenty men abreast, that led up to the men's apartments.

"ði æmɪɝlɪn hɝsɛlf, kʌm wɪð noʊ mɔɹ wɔɹnɪŋ ðən ə pæk pɛdlɝ. mʌs bi kəz ə mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ ən jə sʌðɝnɝz, ɛ? wʌɾ ɛls?"

"The Amyrlin herself, come with no more warning than a pack peddler. Must be because of Moiraine Sedai and you southerners, eh? What else?"

ðə waɪd, aɪɝn-baʊn dɔɹz ə ðə mɛnz əpɑɹtməns stʊɾ oʊpən, ən hæf dʒæmd wɪð tɑp-nɑɾɪd mɛn bʌzɪŋ wɪð ði æmɪɝlɪnz ɝaɪvəl.

The wide, iron-bound doors of the men's apartments stood open, and half jammed with top-knotted men buzzing with the Amyrlin's arrival.

"hoʊ, saʊθlændɝ! ði æmɪɝlɪnz hɪɹ. kʌm fəɹ jə ən jəɹ fɹɛnz, aɪ səpoʊz. pis, wʌɾ ɑnɝ fəɹ ju! ʃi sɛldəm livz tɑɹ vəlɑn, ən ʃiz nɛvɝ kʌm tə ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz ɪn maɪ mɛmɹi."

"Ho, southlander! The Amyrlin's here. Come for you and your friends, I suppose. Peace, what honor for you! She seldom leaves Tar Valon, and she's never come to the Borderlands in my memory."

hi fɛndɪɾ əm ɔl ɔf wɪð ə fju wɝdz. hi hæd tə wɑʃ. faɪn ə klin ʃɝt. noʊ taɪm tə tɔk. ðeɪ θɔt ðeɪ ʌndɝstʊd, ən lɛɾ ɪm ɡoʊ. nɑɾ ə wʌn ə ðɛm nu ə θɪŋ ɪksɛp ðəɾ i ən ɪz fɹɛnz tʃɹævəld ɪn kʌmpəni wɪð ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðət tu ʌv ɪz fɹɛnz wɝ wɪmən u wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn tə tʃɹeɪn əz ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌt ðɛɹ wɝdz stæbd əɾ ɪm əz ɪf ðeɪ nu ɛvɹiθɪŋ. ʃiz kʌm fəɹ mi.

He fended them all off with a few words. He had to wash. Find a clean shirt. No time to talk. They thought they understood, and let him go. Not a one of them knew a thing except that he and his friends traveled in company with an Aes Sedai, that two of his friends were women who were going to Tar Valon to train as Aes Sedai, but their words stabbed at him as if they knew everything. She's come for me.

hi dæʃt θɹu ðə mɛnz əpɑɹtməns, dɑɹɾɪd ɪndə ðə ɹum i ʃɛɹd wɪð mæt ən pɛɹɪn . . . ən fɹoʊz, hɪz dʒɔ dʒɹɑpɪŋ ɪn əstɑnɪʃmənt. ðə ɹum wɑz fɪld wɪð wɪmən wɛɹɪŋ ðə blæk-ænd-ɡoʊld, ɔl wɝkɪŋ pɝpəsfəli. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə bɪɡ ɹum, ən ɪts wɪndoʊz, ə pɛɹ ə tɔl, nɛɹoʊ æɹoʊslɪts lʊkɪŋ daʊn ɑn wʌn ə ði ɪnɝ kɔɹtʃjɑɹdz, dɪd nʌθɪŋ tə meɪk ɪt sim lɑɹdʒɝ. θɹi bɛdz ɑn blæk-ænd-waɪt taɪl plætfɔɹmz, itʃ wɪð ə tʃɛst ət ðə fʊt, θɹi pleɪn tʃɛɹz, ə wɑʃstæn baɪ ðə dɔɹ, ən ə tɔl, waɪd wɔɹdʒɹoʊb kɹaʊɾəd ðə ɹum. ði eɪt wɪmən ɪn ðəɹ sim laɪk fɪʃ ɪn ə bæskət.

He dashed through the men's apartments, darted into the room he shared with Mat and Perrin . . . and froze, his jaw dropping in astonishment. The room was filled with women wearing the black-and-gold, all working purposefully. It was not a big room, and its windows, a pair of tall, narrow arrowslits looking down on one of the inner courtyards, did nothing to make it seem larger. Three beds on black-and-white tiled platforms, each with a chest at the foot, three plain chairs, a washstand by the door, and a tall, wide wardrobe crowded the room. The eight women in there seemed like fish in a basket.

ðə wɪmən bɛɹli ɡlænst ət hɪm, ən wɛn ɹaɪɾ ɑn klɪɹɪŋ ɪz kloʊðz - ən mæts ən pɛɹɪnz - aʊɾ ə ðə wɔɹdʒɹoʊb ən ɹɪpleɪsɪŋ əm wɪð nu. ɛniθɪŋ faʊn ɪn ðə pɑkəts wɑz pʊɾ ətɑp ðə tʃɛsts, ən ði oʊl kloʊðz wɝ bʌndəld ʌp kɛɹləsli, laɪk ɹæɡz.

The women barely glanced at him, and went right on clearing his clothes - and Mat's and Perrin's - out of the wardrobe and replacing them with new. Anything found in the pockets was put atop the chests, and the old clothes were bundled up carelessly, like rags.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ?" hi dɪmændəd wən i kɑɾ ɪz bɹɛθ. "ðoʊz ɑɹ maɪ kloʊðz!" wʌn ə ðə wɪmən snɪft ən poʊkt ə fɪŋɡɝ θɹu ə tiɹ ɪn ðə sliv ə hɪz oʊnli koʊt, ðən æɾəd ɪt tə ðə paɪl ɑn ðə flɔɹ.

"What are you doing?" he demanded when he caught his breath. "Those are my clothes!" One of the women sniffed and poked a finger through a tear in the sleeve of his only coat, then added it to the pile on the floor.

ənʌðɝ, ə blæk-hɛɹd wʊmən wɪð ə bɪɡ ɹɪŋ ə kiz əɾ əɹ weɪst, sɛɾ əɹ aɪz ɑn hɪm. ðət wɑz ilænsu, ʃætʃjən ə ðə kip. hi θɔɾ ə ðə ʃɑɹp-feɪst wʊmən əz ə haʊskipɝ, ðoʊ ðə haʊs ʃi kɛpt wɑz ə fɔɹtʃɹəs ən skɔɹz ə sɝvəns dɪɾ əɹ bɪɾɪŋ. "mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ sɛɾ ɔl ə jəɹ kloʊðz ɑɹ wɔɹn aʊt, ən ðə leɪɾi əmælisə hæd nu meɪd tə ɡɪv ju. dʒʌs kip aʊɾ ʌv əɹ weɪ," ʃi æɾəd fɝmli, "ænd wɪl bi dʌn ðə kwɪkɝ." ðəɹ wɝ fju mɛn ðə ʃætʃjən kəd nɑt bʊli ɪndə duɪŋ əz ʃi wɪʃt - səm sɛɾ ivən lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ - ən ʃi pleɪnli dɪd nɑɾ ɪkspɛkt ɛni tʃɹʌbəl wɪð wʌn mæn jʌŋ ɪnʌf tə bi hɝ sʌn.

Another, a black-haired woman with a big ring of keys at her waist, set her eyes on him. That was Elansu, shatayan of the keep. He thought of the sharp-faced woman as a housekeeper, though the house she kept was a fortress and scores of servants did her bidding. "Moiraine Sedai said all of your clothes are worn out, and the Lady Amalisa had new made to give you. Just keep out of our way," she added firmly, "and we will be done the quicker." There were few men the shatayan could not bully into doing as she wished - some said even Lord Agelmar - and she plainly did not expect any trouble with one man young enough to be her son.

hi swɑloʊd wʌɾ i hæd bɪn ɡoʊɪŋ tə seɪ; ðəɹ wɑz noʊ taɪm fəɹ ɑɹɡjuɪŋ. ði æmɪɝlɪn sit kəd bi sɛndɪŋ fəɹ ɪm əɾ ɛni mɪnət. "ɑnɝ tə ðə leɪɾi əmælisə fəɹ əɹ ɡɪft," hi mænədʒd, æftɝ ðə ʃaɪnɝən weɪ, "æn ɑnɝ tə ju, ilænsu ʃætʃjən. pliz, kənveɪ maɪ wɝdz tə ðə leɪɾi əmælisə, ən tɛl əɹ aɪ sɛd, hɑɹɾ ən soʊl tə sɝv." ðəɾ ɔt tə sæɾəsfaɪ ðə ʃaɪnɝən lʌv ə sɛɹəmoʊni fəɹ boʊθ wɪmən. "bʌt naʊ ɪf jəl pɑɹɾən mi, aɪ wɑnə tʃeɪnʒ."

He swallowed what he had been going to say; there was no time for arguing. The Amyrlin Seat could be sending for him at any minute. "Honor to the Lady Amalisa for her gift," he managed, after the Shienaran way, "and honor to you, Elansu Shatayan. Please, convey my words to the Lady Amalisa, and tell her I said, heart and soul to serve." That ought to satisfy the Shienaran love of ceremony for both women. "But now if you'll pardon me, I want to change."

"ðæɾ ɪz wɛl," ilænsu sɛd kʌmfɝɾəbli. "mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ sɛd tə ɹimuv ɔl ði oʊld. ɛvɹi stɪtʃ. smɔlkloʊðz, tu." sɛvɹəl ə ðə wɪmən aɪɾ ɪm saɪdweɪz. nʌn ə ðɛm meɪɾ ə muv təwɔɹd ðə dɔɹ.

"That is well," Elansu said comfortably. "Moiraine Sedai said to remove all the old. Every stitch. Smallclothes, too." Several of the women eyed him sideways. None of them made a move toward the door.

hi bɪɾ ɪz tʃik tə kip fɹəm læfɪŋ hɪstɛɹɪkli. mɛni weɪz wɝ dɪfɹən ɪn ʃaɪnɝ fɹəm wʌɾ i wɑz juz tə, ən ðəɹ wɝ səm tə wɪtʃ i wəd nɛvɝ bɪkʌm əkʌstəmd ɪf i lɪv fɝɛvɝ. hi hæd teɪkən tə beɪðɪŋ ɪn ðə smɔl aʊɝz ə ðə mɔɹnɪŋ, wən ðə bɪɡ, taɪl pulz wɝ ɛmpti ʌv pipəl, æftɝ i dɪskʌvɝd ðəɾ əɾ ɛni ʌðɝ taɪm ə wʊmən maɪt wɛl klaɪm ɪndə ðə wɔɾɝ wɪð hɪm. ɪt kəd bi ə skʌljən əɹ ðə leɪɾi əmælisə, lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝz sɪstɝ hɝsɛlf - ðə bæθs wɝ wʌn pleɪs ɪn ʃaɪnɝ wɛɹ ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɹæŋk - ɪkspɛktɪŋ ɪm tə skɹʌb əɹ bæk ɪn ɹɪtɝn fəɹ ðə seɪm feɪvɝ, æskɪŋ ɪm waɪ hɪz feɪs wɑz soʊ ɹɛd, hæɾ i teɪkən tu mʌtʃ sʌn? ðeɪ hæd sun lɝn tə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ɪz blʌʃəz fəɹ wʌt ðeɪ wɝ, ən nɑɾ ə wʊmən ɪn ðə kip bʌt sim fæsəneɪɾəd baɪ ðɛm.

He bit his cheek to keep from laughing hysterically. Many ways were different in Shienar from what he was used to, and there were some to which he would never become accustomed if he lived forever. He had taken to bathing in the small hours of the morning, when the big, tiled pools were empty of people, after he discovered that at any other time a woman might well climb into the water with him. It could be a scullion or the Lady Amalisa, Lord Agelmar's sister herself - the baths were one place in Shienar where there was no rank - expecting him to scrub her back in return for the same favor, asking him why his face was so red, had he taken too much sun? They had soon learned to recognize his blushes for what they were, and not a woman in the keep but seemed fascinated by them.

aɪ maɪt bi dɛɾ əɹ wɝs ɪn ənʌðɝ aʊɝ, ən ðəɹ weɪɾɪŋ tə si mi blʌʃ! hi klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊt. "ɪf jəl weɪɾ aʊtsaɪd, əl pæs ðə ɹɛst aʊt tə ju. ɑn maɪ ɑnɝ."

I might be dead or worse in another hour, and they're waiting to see me blush! He cleared his throat. "If you'll wait outside, I will pass the rest out to you. On my honor."

wʌn ə ðə wɪmən ɡeɪv ə sɑf kɔɹɾəl, ən ivən ilænsuz lɪps twɪtʃt, bʌt ðə ʃætʃjən nɑɾəd ən dɝɛktəd ði ʌðɝ wɪmən tə ɡæðɝ ʌp ðə bʌndəlz ðeɪ hæd meɪd. ʃi wɑz ðə læs tə liv, ən ʃi pɔzd ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ tə æd, "ðə buts, tu. mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ sɛɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ."

One of the women gave a soft chortle, and even Elansu's lips twitched, but the shatayan nodded and directed the other women to gather up the bundles they had made. She was the last to leave, and she paused in the doorway to add, "The boots, too. Moiraine Sedai said everything."

hi oʊpən ɪz maʊθ, ðən kloʊzd ɪɾ əɡɛn. hɪz buts, ət list, wɝ sɝɾənli stɪl ɡʊd, meɪd baɪ ælwɪn ælvən, ðə kɑblɝ bæk ɪn ɛmənz fild, ən wɛl bɹoʊkən ɪn ən kʌmftəɹbəl. bʌɾ ɪf ɡɪvɪŋ ʌp ɪz buts wəd meɪk ðə ʃætʃjən liv ɪm əloʊn soʊ hi kəd ɡoʊ, hi wəd ɡɪv əɹ ðə buts, ən ɛniθɪŋ ɛls ʃi wɑntəd. hi hæd noʊ taɪm. "jɛs. jɛs, ʌv kɔɹs. ɑn maɪ ɑnɝ." hi pʊʃt ɑn ðə dɔɹ, fɔɹsɪŋ əɹ aʊt.

He opened his mouth, then closed it again. His boots, at least, were certainly still good, made by Alwyn al'Van, the cobbler back in Emond's Field, and well broken in and comfortable. But if giving up his boots would make the shatayan leave him alone so he could go, he would give her the boots, and anything else she wanted. He had no time. "Yes. Yes, of course. On my honor." He pushed on the door, forcing her out.

əloʊn, hi dʒɹɑpt ɑntu hɪz bɛd tə tʌɡ ɔf ɪz buts - ðeɪ wɝ stɪl ɡʊd, ə lɪɾəl wɔɹn, ðə lɛðɝ kɹæk hɪɹ ən ðɛɹ, bʌt stɪl wɛɹəbəl ən wɛl bɹoʊkən-ɪn tə fɪɾ ɪz fit - ðən heɪstəli stʃɹɪpt ɔf, paɪlɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ətɑp ðə buts, ən wɑʃt ət ðə beɪsən dʒʌst əz kwɪkli. ðə wɔɾɝ wɑz koʊld; ðə wɔɾɝ wɑz ɔlweɪz koʊld ɪn ðə mɛnz əpɑɹtməns.

Alone, he dropped onto his bed to tug off his boots - they were still good, a little worn, the leather cracked here and there, but still wearable and well broken-in to fit his feet - then hastily stripped off, piling everything atop the boots, and washed at the basin just as quickly. The water was cold; the water was always cold in the men's apartments.

ðə wɔɹdʒɹoʊb hæd θɹi waɪd dɔɹz kɑɹvd ɪn ðə sɪmpəl ʃaɪnɝən mænɝ, sədʒɛstɪŋ mɔɹ ðən ʃoʊɪŋ ə sɪɹiz ʌv wɔɾɝfɔlz ən ɹɑki pulz. pʊlɪŋ oʊpən ðə sɛntɝ dɔɹ, hi stɛɹd fəɹ ə moʊmən ət wʌt hæd ɹipleɪs ðə fju ɡɑɹməns i hæd bɹɔt wɪð hɪm. ə dʌzən haɪ-kɑlɝd koʊts ə ðə faɪnəst wʊl ən əz wɛl kʌɾ əz ɛni hi hæɾ ɛvɝ sin ɑn ə mɝtʃəns bæk əɹ ə lɔɹdz, moʊst ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd laɪk fistdeɪ kloʊðz. ə dʌzən! θɹi ʃɝts fəɹ ɛvɹi koʊt, boʊθ lɪnən ən sɪlk, wɪð waɪd slivz ən taɪt kʌfs. tu kloʊks. tu, wən i hæd meɪd də wɪð wʌn əɾ ə taɪm ɔl ɪz laɪf. wʌn kloʊk wɑz pleɪn, staʊt wʊl ən dɑɹk ɡɹin, ði ʌðɝ dip blu wɪð ə stɪf-stændɪŋ kɑlɝ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɪn ɡoʊld wɪð hɛɹənz . . . ən haɪ ɑn ðə lɛf bɹɛst, wɛɹ ə lɔɹd wəd wɛɹ ɪz saɪn. . . .

The wardrobe had three wide doors carved in the simple Shienaran manner, suggesting more than showing a series of waterfalls and rocky pools. Pulling open the center door, he stared for a moment at what had replaced the few garments he had brought with him. A dozen high-collared coats of the finest wool and as well cut as any he had ever seen on a merchant's back or a lord's, most embroidered like feastday clothes. A dozen! Three shirts for every coat, both linen and silk, with wide sleeves and tight cuffs. Two cloaks. Two, when he had made do with one at a time all his life. One cloak was plain, stout wool and dark green, the other deep blue with a stiff-standing collar embroidered in gold with herons . . . and high on the left breast, where a lord would wear his sign. . . .

hɪz hæn dʒɹɪftəd tə ðə kloʊk ʌv ɪts oʊn əkɔɹd. əz ɪf ənsɝɾən wʌt ðeɪ wəd fil, hɪz fɪŋɡɝz bɹʌʃt ðə stɪtʃɪŋ ʌv ə sɝpən kɝld ɔlmoʊst ɪndə ə sɝkəl, bʌɾ ə sɝpənt wɪð fɔɹ lɛɡz ən ə laɪənz ɡoʊldən meɪn, skeɪld ɪn kɹɪmzən ən ɡoʊld, ɪts fiɾ itʃ tɪpt wɪð faɪv ɡoʊldən klɔz. hɪz hæn dʒɝk bæk əz ɪf bɝnd. laɪt hɛlp mi! wɑz ɪɾ əmælisə hæd ðɪs meɪd, əɹ mɔɪɹeɪn? haʊ mɛni sɔ ɪt? haʊ mɛni noʊ wʌɾ ɪɾ ɪz, wʌɾ ɪt minz? ivən wʌn ɪz tu mɛni. bɝn mi, ʃiz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡɛt mi kɪld. blʌɾi mɔɪɹeɪn woʊn ivən tɔk tə mi, bʌt naʊ ʃiz ɡɪvən mi blʌɾi faɪn nu kloʊðz tə daɪ ɪn!

His hand drifted to the cloak of its own accord. As if uncertain what they would feel, his fingers brushed the stitching of a serpent curled almost into a circle, but a serpent with four legs and a lion's golden mane, scaled in crimson and gold, its feet each tipped with five golden claws. His hand jerked back as if burned. Light help me! Was it Amalisa had this made, or Moiraine? How many saw it? How many know what it is, what it means? Even one is too many. Burn me, she's trying to get me killed. Bloody Moiraine won't even talk to me, but now she's given me bloody fine new clothes to die in!

ə ɹæp ət ðə dɔɹ sɛn ɪm lipɪŋ hæf aʊɾ ə hɪz skɪn.

A rap at the door sent him leaping half out of his skin.

"ɑɹ jə dʌn?" keɪm ilænsuz vɔɪs. "ɛvɹi stɪtʃ, naʊ. pɝhæps aɪ hæd bɛɾɝ. . . ." ə kɹik əz ɪf ʃi wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ ðə nɑb.

"Are you done?" came Elansu's voice. "Every stitch, now. Perhaps I had better. . . ." A creak as if she were trying the knob.

wɪð ə stɑɹt ɹænd ɹilaɪzd i wɑz stɪl neɪkəd. "aɪm dʌn," hi ʃaʊɾəd. "pis! doʊn kʌm ɪn!" hɝidli hi ɡæðɝɾ ʌp wʌɾ i hæd bɪn wɛɹɪŋ, buts ən ɔl. "aɪl bɹɪŋ ðɛm!" haɪɾɪŋ bɪhaɪn ðə dɔɹ, hi oʊpən ɪt dʒʌst waɪɾ ɪnʌf tə ʃʌv ðə bʌndəl ɪndə ði ɑɹmz ə ðə ʃætʃjən. "ðæts ɛvɹiθɪŋ."

With a start Rand realized he was still naked. "I'm done," he shouted. "Peace! Don't come in!" Hurriedly he gathered up what he had been wearing, boots and all. "I'll bring them!" Hiding behind the door, he opened it just wide enough to shove the bundle into the arms of the shatayan. "That's everything."

ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə pɪɹ θɹu ðə ɡæp. "ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ? mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ sɛɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ. pɝhæps aɪ hæd bɛɾɝ dʒʌs lʊk - "

She tried to peer through the gap. "Are you sure? Moiraine Sedai said everything. Perhaps I had better just look - "

"ɪts ɛvɹiθɪŋ," hi ɡɹaʊld. "ɑn maɪ ɑnɝ!" hi ʃoʊldɝd ðə dɔɹ ʃʌɾ ɪn əɹ feɪs, ən hɝd læftɝ fɹəm ði ʌðɝ saɪd.

"It's everything," he growled. "On my honor!" He shouldered the door shut in her face, and heard laughter from the other side.

mʌɾɝɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ, hi dʒɹɛs hɝidli. hi wəd nɑt pʊɾ ɪt pæst ɛni ʌv əm tə faɪn səm ɪkskjus tə kʌm bʊlɪŋ ɪn ɛniweɪ. ðə ɡɹeɪ bɹitʃɪz wɝ snʌɡɡɝ ðən i wɑz juz tə, bʌt stɪl kʌmftəɹbəl, ən ðə ʃɝt, wɪð ɪts bɪloʊi slivz, wɑz waɪɾ ɪnʌf tə sæɾəsfaɪ ɛni ɡʊdwaɪf ɪn ɛmənz fild ɑn lɔnʒɹi deɪ. ðə ni-haɪ buts fɪɾ əz ɪf i hæd wɔɹn əm ə jɪɹ. hi hoʊpt ɪt wɑz dʒʌst ə ɡʊd kɑblɝ, ən nɑt mɔɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝk.

Muttering under his breath, he dressed hurriedly. He would not put it past any of them to find some excuse to come bulling in anyway. The gray breeches were snugger than he was used to, but still comfortable, and the shirt, with its billowy sleeves, was white enough to satisfy any goodwife in Emond's Field on laundry day. The knee-high boots fit as if he had worn them a year. He hoped it was just a good cobbler, and not more Aes Sedai work.

ɔl ə ðiz kloʊðz wəd meɪk ə pæk əz bɪɡ əz i wɑz. jɛt, hi hæd ɡɹoʊn juz tə ðə kʌmfɝɾ ə klin ʃɝts əɡɛn, ʌv nɑt wɛɹɪŋ ðə seɪm bɹitʃɪz deɪ æftɝ deɪ əntɪl swɛɾ ən dɝt meɪɾ əm əz stɪf əz ɪz buts, ðən wɛɹɪŋ əm stɪl. hi tʊk ɪz sæɾəlbæɡz fɹəm ɪz tʃɛst ən stʌft wʌɾ i kəɾ ɪndə ðɛm, ðən ɹɪlʌktənli spɹɛd ðə fænsi kloʊk aʊɾ ɑn ðə bɛɾ ən paɪld ə fju mɔɹ ʃɝts ən bɹitʃɪz ɑn ðæt. foʊldəd wɪð ðə deɪnʒɝəs sɪdʒəl ɪnsaɪɾ ən taɪd wɪð ə kɔɹd lup soʊ ɪt kəd bi slʌŋ ɑn ə ʃoʊldɝ, ɪt lʊk nɑt mʌtʃ dɪfɹən fɹəm ðə pæks i hæd sin kæɹid baɪ ʌðɝ jʌŋ mɛn ɑn ðə ɹoʊd.

All of these clothes would make a pack as big as he was. Yet, he had grown used to the comfort of clean shirts again, of not wearing the same breeches day after day until sweat and dirt made them as stiff as his boots, then wearing them still. He took his saddlebags from his chest and stuffed what he could into them, then reluctantly spread the fancy cloak out on the bed and piled a few more shirts and breeches on that. Folded with the dangerous sigil inside and tied with a cord looped so it could be slung on a shoulder, it looked not much different from the packs he had seen carried by other young men on the road.

ə pil ə tʃɹʌmpəts ɹoʊl θɹu ði æɹoʊslɪts, tʃɹʌmpəts kɔlɪŋ ðə fænfɛɹ fɹəm aʊtsaɪd ðə wɔlz, tʃɹʌmpəts ænsɝɪŋ fɹəm ðə kip taʊɝz.

A peal of trumpets rolled through the arrowslits, trumpets calling the fanfare from outside the walls, trumpets answering from the keep towers.

"aɪl pɪk aʊt ðə stɪtʃɪŋ wən aɪ ɡɛɾ ə tʃæns," hi mʌɾɝd. hi hæd sin wɪmən pɪkɪŋ aʊɾ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi wən ðeɪ hæd meɪɾ ə mɪsteɪk əɹ tʃeɪnʒd ðɛɹ maɪn ɑn ðə pæɾɝn, ən ɪt dɪd nɑt lʊk vɛɹi hɑɹd.

"I'll pick out the stitching when I get a chance," he muttered. He had seen women picking out embroidery when they had made a mistake or changed their mind on the pattern, and it did not look very hard.

ðə ɹɛst ə ðə kloʊðz - moʊst ə ðɛm, ɪn fækt - hi stʌf bæk ɪndə ðə wɔɹdʒɹoʊb. noʊ nid tə liv ɛvəɾəns ə flaɪt tə bi faʊn baɪ ðə fɝs pɝsən tə poʊk ə hɛɾ ɪn æftɝ i wɛnt.

The rest of the clothes - most of them, in fact - he stuffed back into the wardrobe. No need to leave evidence of flight to be found by the first person to poke a head in after he went.

stɪl fɹaʊnɪŋ, hi nɛl bɪsaɪɾ ɪz bɛd. ðə taɪl plætfɔɹmz ɑn wɪtʃ ðə bɛdz ɹɛstəd wɝ stoʊvz, wɛɹ ə smɔl faɪɝ dæmp daʊn tə bɝn ɔl naɪt kəd kip ðə bɛd wɔɹm θɹu ðə wɝs naɪɾ ɪn ə ʃaɪnɝən wɪntɝ. ðə naɪts wɝ stɪl kulɝ ðən i wɑz juz tə ðɪs taɪm ə jɪɹ, bʌt blæŋkəts wɝ ɪnʌf fəɹ wɔɹmθ naʊ. pʊlɪŋ oʊpən ðə faɪɝbɑks dɔɹ, hi tʊk aʊɾ ə bʌndəl i kəd nɑt liv bɪhaɪnd. hi wɑz ɡlæɾ ilænsu hæd nɑt θɔɾ ɛniwʌn wəd kip kloʊðz ɪn ðɛɹ.

Still frowning, he knelt beside his bed. The tiled platforms on which the beds rested were stoves, where a small fire damped down to burn all night could keep the bed warm through the worst night in a Shienaran winter. The nights were still cooler than he was used to this time of year, but blankets were enough for warmth now. Pulling open the firebox door, he took out a bundle he could not leave behind. He was glad Elansu had not thought anyone would keep clothes in there.

sɛɾɪŋ ðə bʌndəl ətɑp ðə blæŋkəts, hi əntaɪd wʌn ɛn ən pɑɹʃəli ənfoʊldəɾ ɪt. ə ɡlimənz kloʊk, tɝn ɪnsaɪɾ aʊt tə haɪd ðə hʌnʒɹədz ə pætʃəz ðət kʌvɝɾ ɪt, pætʃəz ɪn ɛvɹi saɪz ən kʌlɝ ɪmædʒənəbəl. ðə kloʊk ɪtsɛlf wɑz saʊn ɪnʌf; ðə pætʃəz wɝ ə ɡlimənz bædʒ. hæd bɪn ə ɡlimənz bædʒ.

Setting the bundle atop the blankets, he untied one end and partially unfolded it. A gleeman's cloak, turned inside out to hide the hundreds of patches that covered it, patches in every size and color imaginable. The cloak itself was sound enough; the patches were a gleeman's badge. Had been a gleeman's badge.

ɪnsaɪd nɛsəl tu hɑɹd lɛðɝ keɪsəz. ðə lɑɹdʒɝ hɛld ə hɑɹp, wɪtʃ i nɛvɝ tʌtʃt. ðə hɑɹp wɑz nɛvɝ mɛn fəɹ ə fɑɹmɝz klʌmzi fɪŋɡɝz, bɔɪ. ði ʌðɝ, lɔŋ ən slɪm, kənteɪn ðə ɡoʊld-ænd-sɪlvɝ tʃeɪs fluɾ i hæd juz tə ɝn ɪz sʌpɝ ən bɛd mɔɹ ðən wʌns sɪns livɪŋ hoʊm. tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn hæd tɔɾ ɪm tə pleɪ ðət flut, bɪfɔɹ ðə ɡlimən daɪd. ɹænd kəd nɛvɝ tʌtʃ ɪt wɪθaʊt ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ tɑm, wɪð ɪz ʃɑɹp blu aɪz ən ɪz lɔŋ waɪt mʌstæʃɪz, ʃʌvɪŋ ðə bʌndəl kloʊk ɪndə hɪz hænz ən ʃaʊɾɪŋ fəɹ ɪm tə ɹʌn. ən ðən tɑm hæd ɹʌn hɪmsɛlf, naɪvz əpɪɹɪŋ mædʒɪkəli ɪn ɪz hænz əz ɪf i wɝ pɝfɔɹmɪŋ, tə feɪs ðə mɹdʒɹɑl ðət wɑz kʌmɪŋ tə kɪl ðɛm.

Inside nestled two hard leather cases. The larger held a harp, which he never touched. The harp was never meant for a farmer's clumsy fingers, boy. The other, long and slim, contained the gold-and-silver chased flute he had used to earn his supper and bed more than once since leaving home. Thom Merrilin had taught him to play that flute, before the gleeman died. Rand could never touch it without remembering Thom, with his sharp blue eyes and his long white mustaches, shoving the bundled cloak into his hands and shouting for him to run. And then Thom had run himself, knives appearing magically in his hands as if he were performing, to face the Myrddraal that was coming to kill them.

wɪð ə ʃɪvɝ, hi ɹidɪd ðə bʌndəl. "ðæts ɔl oʊvɝ wɪð." θɪŋkɪŋ ə ðə wɪn ɑn ðə taʊɝ tɑp, hi æɾəd, "stʃɹeɪnʒ θɪŋz hæpən ðɪs kloʊs tə ðə blaɪt." hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ i bɪlivd ɪt, nɑt ðə weɪ læn hæɾ əpɛɹənli mɛn ɪt. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ivən wɪθaʊt ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, ɪt wɑz pæs taɪm fəɹ ɪm tə bi ɡɔn fɹəm fæl dæɹə.

With a shiver, he redid the bundle. "That's all over with." Thinking of the wind on the tower top, he added, "Strange things happen this close to the Blight." He was not sure he believed it, not the way Lan had apparently meant it. In any case, even without the Amyrlin Seat, it was past time for him to be gone from Fal Dara.

ʃɹʌɡɪŋ ɪndə ðə koʊɾ i hæd kɛpt aʊt - ɪt wɑz ə dip, dɑɹk ɡɹin, ən meɪɾ ɪm θɪŋk ə ðə fɔɹəsts ət hoʊm, tæmz wɛstwʊd fɑɹm wɛɹ i hæd ɡɹoʊn ʌp, ən ðə wɔɾɝwʊd wɛɹ i hæd lɝn tə swɪm - hi bʌkəl ðə hɛɹən-mɑɹk sɔɹd tə hɪz weɪst ən hʌŋ ɪz kwɪvɝ, bɹɪsəlɪŋ wɪð æɹoʊz, ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd. hɪz ənstʃɹʌŋ baʊ stʊd pɹɑpt ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ wɪð mæts ən pɛɹɪnz, ðə steɪv tu hænz tɔlɝ ðən i wɑz. hi hæd meɪɾ ɪt hɪmsɛlf sɪns kʌmɪŋ tə fæl dæɹə, ən bɪsaɪdz hɪm, oʊnli læn ən pɛɹɪn kəd dʒɹɔ ɪt. stʌfɪŋ ɪz blæŋkɪtʃɹoʊl ən ɪz nu kloʊk θɹu ðə lups ɑn ɪz bʌndəlz, hi slʌŋ ðə pɛɹ fɹəm ɪz lɛft ʃoʊldɝ, tɔst ɪz sæɾəlbæɡz ətɑp ðə kɔɹdz, ən ɡɹæb ðə baʊ. liv ðə sɔɹd-ɑɹm fɹi, hi θɔt. meɪk əm θɪŋk aɪm deɪnʒɝəs. meɪbi sʌmbɑɾi wɪl.

Shrugging into the coat he had kept out - it was a deep, dark green, and made him think of the forests at home, Tam's Westwood farm where he had grown up, and the Waterwood where he had learned to swim - he buckled the heron-mark sword to his waist and hung his quiver, bristling with arrows, on the other side. His unstrung bow stood propped in the corner with Mat's and Perrin's, the stave two hands taller than he was. He had made it himself since coming to Fal Dara, and besides him, only Lan and Perrin could draw it. Stuffing his blanketroll and his new cloak through the loops on his bundles, he slung the pair from his left shoulder, tossed his saddlebags atop the cords, and grabbed the bow. Leave the sword-arm free, he thought. Make them think I'm dangerous. Maybe somebody will.

kɹækɪŋ ðə dɔɹ ɹɪvil ðə hɔl ɔl bʌɾ ɛmpti; wʌn lɪvɹid sɝvən dæʃt baɪ, bʌɾ i nɛvɝ soʊ mʌtʃ əz ɡlænst ət ɹænd. əz sun əz ðə mænz ɹæpəd fʊtfɔlz feɪɾəd, ɹænd slɪpt aʊɾ ɪndə ðə kɔɹəɾɝ.

Cracking the door revealed the hall all but empty; one liveried servant dashed by, but he never so much as glanced at Rand. As soon as the man's rapid footfalls faded, Rand slipped out into the corridor.

hi tʃɹaɪd tə wɔk nætʃɹəli, kæʒəwəli, bʌt wɪð sæɾəlbæɡz ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ən bʌndəlz ɑn ɪz bæk, hi nu hi lʊk laɪk wʌɾ i wɑz, ə mæn sɛɾɪŋ aʊɾ ɑn ə dʒɝni ən nɑt minɪŋ tə kʌm bæk. ðə tʃɹʌmpəts kɔld əɡɛn, saʊndɪŋ feɪntɝ hɪɹ ɪnsaɪd ðə kip.

He tried to walk naturally, casually, but with saddlebags on his shoulder and bundles on his back, he knew he looked like what he was, a man setting out on a journey and not meaning to come back. The trumpets called again, sounding fainter here inside the keep.

hi hæɾ ə hɔɹs, ə tɔl beɪ stæljən, ɪn ðə nɔɹθ steɪbəl, kɔl ðə lɔɹdz steɪbəl, kloʊs baɪ ðə sæli ɡeɪt ðət lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ juzd wən i wɛn ɹaɪɾɪŋ. niðɝ ðə lɔɹɾ ə fæl dæɹə nɔɹ ɛni ʌv ɪz fæmli wəd bi ɹaɪɾɪŋ tədeɪ, ðoʊ, ən ðə steɪbəl maɪt bi ɛmpti ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə steɪbəlbɔɪz. ðəɹ wɝ tu weɪz tə ɹitʃ ðə lɔɹdz steɪbəl fɹəm ɹændz ɹum. wʌn wəd teɪk ɪm ɔl ðə weɪ ɝaʊn ðə kip, bɪhaɪn lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝz pɹaɪvət ɡɑɹɾən, ðən daʊn ðə fɑɹ saɪɾ ən θɹu ðə fɛɹiɝz smɪθi, laɪkwaɪz sɝɾənli ɛmpti naʊ, tə ðə steɪbliɑɹd. taɪm ɪnʌf ðət weɪ fəɹ ɔɹɾɝz tə bi ɡɪvən, fəɹ ə sɝtʃ tə stɑɹt, bɪfɔɹ i ɹitʃt ɪz hɔɹs. ði ʌðɝ wɑz fɑɹ ʃɔɹɾɝ; fɝst əkɹɔs ði aʊɾɝ kɔɹtʃjɑɹd, wɛɹ ivən naʊ ði æmɪɝlɪn sit wɑz ɝaɪvɪŋ wɪð ənʌðɝ dʌzən əɹ mɔɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ.

He had a horse, a tall bay stallion, in the north stable, called the Lord's Stable, close by the salley gate that Lord Agelmar used when he went riding. Neither the Lord of Fal Dara nor any of his family would be riding today, though, and the stable might be empty except for the stableboys. There were two ways to reach the Lord's Stable from Rand's room. One would take him all the way around the keep, behind Lord Agelmar's private garden, then down the far side and through the farrier's smithy, likewise certainly empty now, to the stableyard. Time enough that way for orders to be given, for a search to start, before he reached his horse. The other was far shorter; first across the outer courtyard, where even now the Amyrlin Seat was arriving with another dozen or more Aes Sedai.

hɪz skɪn pɹɪkəld ət ðə θɔt; hi hæd hæd mɔɹ ðən ɪnʌf ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ fəɹ ɛni seɪn laɪftaɪm. wʌn wɑz tu mɛni. ɔl ðə stɔɹiz sɛɾ ɪt, ən i nu ɪt fəɹ fækt. bʌɾ i wɑz nɑt sɝpɹaɪzd wən ɪz fit tʊk ɪm təwɔɹd ði aʊɾɝ kɔɹtʃjɑɹd. hi wəd nɛvɝ si lɛdʒəndɛɹi tɑɹ vəlɑn - hi kəd nɑɾ əfɔɹd ðət ɹɪsk, naʊ əɹ ɛvɝ - bʌɾ i maɪt kætʃ ə ɡlɪmps ə ði æmɪɝlɪn sit bɪfɔɹ i lɛft. ðət wəd bi əz mʌtʃ əz siɪŋ ə kwin. ðəɹ kæn bi ɛniθɪŋ deɪnʒɝəs ɪn dʒʌs lʊkɪŋ, fɹəm ə dɪstəns. əl kip muvɪŋ ən bi ɡɔn bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɛvɝ noʊz aɪ wɑz ðɛɹ.

His skin prickled at the thought; he had had more than enough of Aes Sedai for any sane lifetime. One was too many. All the stories said it, and he knew it for fact. But he was not surprised when his feet took him toward the outer courtyard. He would never see legendary Tar Valon - he could not afford that risk, now or ever - but he might catch a glimpse of the Amyrlin Seat before he left. That would be as much as seeing a queen. There can't be anything dangerous in just looking, from a distance. I'll keep moving and be gone before she ever knows I was there.

hi oʊpən ə hɛvi, aɪɝn-stʃɹæp dɔɹ ɑntu ði aʊɾɝ kɔɹtʃjɑɹɾ ən stɛpt aʊɾ ɪndə saɪləns. pipəl fɔɹəstəd ðə ɡɑɹdwɔk ətɑp ɛvɹi wɔl, tɑp-nɑɾɪd soʊlʒɝz, ən lɪvɹid sɝvəns, ən minaɪəlz stɪl ɪn ðɛɹ mʌk, ɔl pɹɛs təɡɛðɝ tʃik baɪ dʒaʊl, wɪð tʃɪlʒɹən sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ʃoʊldɝz tə lʊk oʊvɝ ðɛɹ ɛldɝz' hɛdz əɹ skwizɪŋ ɪn tə pɪɹ ɝaʊnd weɪsts ən niz. ɛvɹi ɑɹtʃɝz' bælkəni wɑz pæk laɪk ə bæɹəl ʌv æpəlz, ən feɪsəz ivən ʃoʊɾ ɪn ðə nɛɹoʊ æɹoʊslɪts ɪn ðə wɔlz. ə θɪk mæs ə pipəl bɔɹɾɝd ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd laɪk ənʌðɝ wɔl. ən ɔl ə ðɛm wɑtʃt ən weɪɾəd ɪn saɪləns.

He opened a heavy, iron-strapped door onto the outer courtyard and stepped out into silence. People forested the guardwalk atop every wall, top-knotted soldiers, and liveried servants, and menials still in their muck, all pressed together cheek by jowl, with children sitting on shoulders to look over their elders' heads or squeezing in to peer around waists and knees. Every archers' balcony was packed like a barrel of apples, and faces even showed in the narrow arrowslits in the walls. A thick mass of people bordered the courtyard like another wall. And all of them watched and waited in silence.

hi pʊʃt ɪz weɪ əlɔŋ ðə wɔl, ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə smɪθiz ən flɛtʃɝz' stɔlz ðət laɪn ðə kɔɹt - fæl dæɹə wɑz ə fɔɹtʃɹəs, nɑɾ ə pæləs, dɪspaɪɾ ɪts saɪz ən ɡɹɪm ɡɹænduɹ, ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt sɝv ðəɾ ɛnd - əpɑlədʒaɪzɪŋ kwaɪətli tə ðə pipəl i dʒɑsəld. səm lʊkt ɝaʊnd wɪð ə fɹaʊn, ən ə fju ɡeɪv ə sɛkən stɛɹ tə hɪz sæɾəlbæɡz ən bʌndəlz, bʌt nʌn bɹoʊk ðə saɪləns. moʊs dɪd nɑɾ ivən bɑðɝ tə lʊk əɾ u hæd bʌmpt pæs ðɛm.

He pushed his way along the wall, in front of the smithies and fletchers' stalls that lined the court - Fal Dara was a fortress, not a palace, despite its size and grim grandeur, and everything about it served that end - apologizing quietly to the people he jostled. Some looked around with a frown, and a few gave a second stare to his saddlebags and bundles, but none broke the silence. Most did not even bother to look at who had bumped past them.

hi kəɾ izəli si oʊvɝ ðə hɛdz ə moʊst ə ðɛm, ɪnʌf tə meɪk aʊt klɪɹli wʌt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn ɪn ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd. dʒʌst ɪnsaɪd ðə meɪn ɡeɪt, ə laɪn ə mɛn stʊd bɪsaɪd ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz, fɔɹtin ə ðɛm. noʊ tu wɔɹ ðə seɪm kaɪndə ɑɹmɝ əɹ kæɹid ðə seɪm sɔɹɾ ə sɔɹd, ən nʌn lʊk laɪk læn, bʌt ɹænd dɪd nɑt daʊt ðeɪ wɝ wɔɹɾɝz. ɹaʊn feɪsəz, skwɛɹ feɪsəz, lɔŋ feɪsəz, nɛɹoʊ feɪsəz, ðeɪ ɔl hæd ðə lʊk, əz ɪf ðeɪ sɔ θɪŋz ʌðɝ mɛn dɪd nɑt si, hɝd θɪŋz ʌðɝ mɛn dɪd nɑt hɪɹ. stændɪŋ ət ðɛɹ iz, ðeɪ lʊkt əz dɛdli əz ə pæk ʌv wʊlvz. oʊnli wʌn ʌðɝ θɪŋ əbaʊɾ əm wɑz əlaɪk. wʌn ən ɔl ðeɪ wɔɹ ðə kʌlɝ-ʃɪftɪŋ kloʊk i hæd fɝst sin ɑn læn, ðə kloʊk ðəɾ ɔfən sim tə feɪɾ ɪndə wʌtɛvɝ wɑz bɪhaɪn ɪt. ɪt dɪd nɑt meɪk fəɹ izi wɑtʃɪŋ əɹ ə stɪl stʌmək, soʊ mɛni mɛn ɪn ðoʊz kloʊks.

He could easily see over the heads of most of them, enough to make out clearly what was going on in the courtyard. Just inside the main gate, a line of men stood beside their horses, fourteen of them. No two wore the same kind of armor or carried the same sort of sword, and none looked like Lan, but Rand did not doubt they were Warders. Round faces, square faces, long faces, narrow faces, they all had the look, as if they saw things other men did not see, heard things other men did not hear. Standing at their ease, they looked as deadly as a pack of wolves. Only one other thing about them was alike. One and all they wore the color-shifting cloak he had first seen on Lan, the cloak that often seemed to fade into whatever was behind it. It did not make for easy watching or a still stomach, so many men in those cloaks.

ə dʌzən peɪsɪz ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə wɔɹɾɝz, ə ɹoʊ ʌv wɪmən stʊd baɪ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz' hɛdz, ðə kaʊlz ə ðɛɹ kloʊks θɹoʊn bæk. hi kəd kaʊn ðɛm, naʊ. fɔɹtin. fɔɹtin ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðeɪ mʌs bi. tɔl ən ʃɔɹt, slɛndɝ ən plʌmp, dɑɹk ən fɛɹ, hɛɹ kʌt ʃɔɹɾ əɹ lɔŋ, hæŋɪŋ lus daʊn ðɛɹ bæks əɹ bɹeɪɾɪd, ðɛɹ kloʊðz wɝ əz dɪfɹən əz ðə wɔɹɾɝz' wɝ, ɪn əz mɛni kʌts ən kʌlɝz əz ðəɹ wɝ wɪmən. jɛt ðeɪ, tu, hæɾ ə seɪmnəs, wʌn ðət wɑz oʊnli ɑbviəs wən ðeɪ stʊd təɡɛðɝ laɪk ðɪs. tə ə wʊmən, ðeɪ simd eɪdʒləs. fɹəm ðɪs dɪstəns i wʊɾə kɔld əm ɔl jʌŋ, bʌt kloʊsɝ i nu ðeɪ wəd bi laɪk mɔɪɹeɪn. jʌŋ-simɪŋ jɛt nɑt, smuð-skɪn bʌt wɪð feɪsəz tu mətʃʊɹ fəɹ juθ, aɪz tu noʊɪŋ.

A dozen paces in front of the Warders, a row of women stood by their horses' heads, the cowls of their cloaks thrown back. He could count them, now. Fourteen. Fourteen Aes Sedai. They must be. Tall and short, slender and plump, dark and fair, hair cut short or long, hanging loose down their backs or braided, their clothes were as different as the Warders' were, in as many cuts and colors as there were women. Yet they, too, had a sameness, one that was only obvious when they stood together like this. To a woman, they seemed ageless. From this distance he would have called them all young, but closer he knew they would be like Moiraine. Young-seeming yet not, smooth-skinned but with faces too mature for youth, eyes too knowing.

kloʊsɝ? ful! aɪm tu kloʊs ɔlɹɛɾi! bɝn mi, aɪ ʃʊɾə ɡɔn ðə lɔŋ weɪ. hi pɹɛst ɑn təwɔɹɾ ɪz ɡoʊl, ənʌðɝ aɪɝn-baʊn dɔɹ ət ðə fɑɹ ɛn ə ðə kɔɹt, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt stɑp lʊkɪŋ.

Closer? Fool! I'm too close already! Burn me, I should have gone the long way. He pressed on toward his goal, another iron-bound door at the far end of the court, but he could not stop looking.

kɑmli ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪɡnɔɹd ði ɔnlʊkɝz ən kɛp ðɛɹ ətɛnʃən ɑn ðə kɝteɪn pɑlɑnkwɪn, naʊ ɪn ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd. ðə hɔɹsəz bɛɹɪŋ ɪt hɛld əz stɪl əz ɪf ɑslɝz stʊɾ ət ðɛɹ hɑɹnəs, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli wʌn tɔl wʊmən bɪsaɪd ðə pɑlɑnkwɪn, hɝ feɪs ən ɛɛs sədaɪz feɪs, ən ʃi peɪd noʊ maɪn tə ðə hɔɹsəz. ðə stæf ʃi hɛld əpɹaɪt bɪfɔɹ əɹ wɪð boʊθ hænz wɑz əz tɔl əz ʃi, ðə ɡɪldɪd fleɪm kæpɪŋ ɪt stændɪŋ əbʌv əɹ aɪz.

Calmly the Aes Sedai ignored the onlookers and kept their attention on the curtained palanquin, now in the center of the courtyard. The horses bearing it held as still as if ostlers stood at their harness, but there was only one tall woman beside the palanquin, her face an Aes Sedai's face, and she paid no mind to the horses. The staff she held upright before her with both hands was as tall as she, the gilded flame capping it standing above her eyes.

lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ feɪs ðə pɑlɑnkwɪn fɹəm ðə fɑɹ ɛn ə ðə kɔɹt, blʌf ən skwɛɹ ən feɪs ənɹiɾəbəl. hɪz haɪ-kɑlɝd koʊɾ ə dɑɹk blu bɔɹ ðə θɹi ɹʌnɪŋ ɹɛd fɑksəz ə ðə haʊs dʒəɡəɾ əz wɛl əz ðə stupɪŋ blæk hɔk ə ʃaɪnɝ. bɪsaɪɾ ɪm stʊd ɹoʊnən, eɪdʒ-wɪðɝd bʌt stɪl tɔl; θɹi fɑksəz kɑɹv fɹəm ɹɛɾ æveɪtin tɑp ðə tɔl stæf ðə ʃæmbaɪən bɔɹ. ɹoʊnən wɑz ilænsuz ikwəl ɪn ɔɹɾɝɪŋ ðə kip, ʃæmbaɪən ən ʃætʃjən, bʌɾ ilænsu lɛf lɪɾəl fəɹ ɪm ɪksɛp sɛɹəmoʊniz ən æktɪŋ əz lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝz sɛkɹətɛɹi. boʊθ mɛnz tɑpnɑts wɝ snoʊ-waɪt.

Lord Agelmar faced the palanquin from the far end of the court, bluff and square and face unreadable. His high-collared coat of dark blue bore the three running red foxes of the House Jagad as well as the stooping black hawk of Shienar. Beside him stood Ronan, age-withered but still tall; three foxes carved from red avatine topped the tall staff the shambayan bore. Ronan was Elansu's equal in ordering the keep, shambayan and shatayan, but Elansu left little for him except ceremonies and acting as Lord Agelmar's secretary. Both men's topknots were snow-white.

ɔl ə ðɛm - ðə wɔɹɾɝz, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðə lɔɹɾ ə fæl dæɹə, ən ɪz ʃæmbaɪən - stʊɾ əz stɪl əz stoʊn. ðə wɑtʃɪŋ kɹaʊd sim tə hoʊld ɪts bɹɛθ. dɪspaɪt hɪmsɛlf, ɹænd sloʊd.

All of them - the Warders, the Aes Sedai, the Lord of Fal Dara, and his shambayan - stood as still as stone. The watching crowd seemed to hold its breath. Despite himself, Rand slowed.

sʌɾənli ɹoʊnən ɹæpt ɪz stæf laʊdli θɹi taɪmz ɑn ðə bɹɔd peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz, kɔlɪŋ ɪndə ðə saɪləns, "hu kʌmz hɪɹ? hu kʌmz hɪɹ? hu kʌmz hɪɹ?"

Suddenly Ronan rapped his staff loudly three times on the broad paving stones, calling into the silence, "Who comes here? Who comes here? Who comes here?"

ðə wʊmən bɪsaɪd ðə pɑlɑnkwɪn tæpt əɹ stæf θɹi taɪmz ɪn ɹɪplaɪ. "ðə wɑtʃɝ ə ðə silz. ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn. ði æmɪɝlɪn sit."

The woman beside the palanquin tapped her staff three times in reply. "The Watcher of the Seals. The Flame of Tar Valon. The Amyrlin Seat."

"waɪ ʃəd wi wɑtʃ?" ɹoʊnən dɪmændəd.

"Why should we watch?" Ronan demanded.

"fɔɹ ðə hoʊp ə hjumənkaɪnd," ðə tɔl wʊmən ɹɪplaɪd.

"For the hope of humankind," the tall woman replied.

"əɡɛnst wʌt də wi ɡɑɹd?"

"Against what do we guard?"

"ðə ʃædoʊ ət nun."

"The shadow at noon."

"haʊ lɔŋ ʃæl wi ɡɑɹd?"

"How long shall we guard?"

"fɹʌm ɹaɪzɪŋ sʌn tə ɹaɪzɪŋ sʌn, soʊ lɔŋ əz ðə wil ə taɪm tɝnz."

"From rising sun to rising sun, so long as the Wheel of Time turns."

eɪɡəlmɝ baʊd, hɪz waɪt tɑpnɑt stɝɪŋ ɪn ðə bɹiz. "fæl dæɹə ɔfɝz bɹɛɾ ən sɔlt ən wɛlkəm. wɛl kʌm ɪz ði æmɪɝlɪn sit tə fæl dæɹə, fəɹ hɪɹ ɪz ðə wɑtʃ kɛpt, hɪɹ ɪz ðə pæk meɪnteɪnd. wɛlkəm."

Agelmar bowed, his white topknot stirring in the breeze. "Fal Dara offers bread and salt and welcome. Well come is the Amyrlin Seat to Fal Dara, for here is the watch kept, here is the Pact maintained. Welcome."

ðə tɔl wʊmən dʒɹu bæk ðə kɝɾən ə ðə pɑlɑnkwɪn, ən ði æmɪɝlɪn sit stɛpt aʊt. dɑɹk-hɛɹd, eɪdʒləs əz ɔl ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ eɪdʒləs, ʃi ɹæn əɹ aɪz oʊvɝ ði əsɛmbəld wɑtʃɝz əz ʃi stʃɹeɪɾənd. ɹænd flɪntʃt wən əɹ ɡeɪz kɹɔs hɪm; hi fɛlt əz ɪf i hæd bɪn tʌtʃt. bʌɾ əɹ aɪz pæst ɑn ən keɪm tə ɹɛst ɑn lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ. ə lɪvɹid sɝvənt nɛlt əɾ əɹ saɪd wɪð foʊldəd taʊəlz, stim stɪl ɹaɪzɪŋ, ɑn ə sɪlvɝ tʃɹeɪ. fɔɹməli, ʃi waɪpt əɹ hænz ən pæɾəd əɹ feɪs wɪð ə dæmp klɔθ. "aɪ ɔfɝ θæŋks fəɹ jəɹ wɛlkəm, maɪ sʌn. meɪ ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin haʊs dʒəɡəd. meɪ ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin fæl dæɹə ən ɔl əɹ pipəl."

The tall woman drew back the curtain of the palanquin, and the Amyrlin Seat stepped out. Dark-haired, ageless as all Aes Sedai were ageless, she ran her eyes over the assembled watchers as she straightened. Rand flinched when her gaze crossed him; he felt as if he had been touched. But her eyes passed on and came to rest on Lord Agelmar. A liveried servant knelt at her side with folded towels, steam still rising, on a silver tray. Formally, she wiped her hands and patted her face with a damp cloth. "I offer thanks for your welcome, my son. May the Light illumine House Jagad. May the Light illumine Fal Dara and all her people."

eɪɡəlmɝ baʊɾ əɡɛn. "ju ɑnɝ ʌs, mʌðɝ." ɪt dɪd nɑt saʊn ɑd, hɝ kɔlɪŋ ɪm sʌn əɹ ɪm kɔlɪŋ əɹ mʌðɝ, ðoʊ kəmpɛɹɪŋ əɹ smuð tʃiks tə hɪz kɹæɡi feɪs meɪɾ ɪm sim mɔɹ laɪk əɹ fɑðɝ, əɹ ivən ɡɹændfɑðɝ. ʃi hæɾ ə pɹɛzəns ðət mɔɹ ðən mætʃt hɪz. "haʊs dʒəɡəɾ ɪz jʊɹz. fæl dæɹə ɪz jʊɹz."

Agelmar bowed again. "You honor us, Mother." It did not sound odd, her calling him son or him calling her Mother, though comparing her smooth cheeks to his craggy face made him seem more like her father, or even grandfather. She had a presence that more than matched his. "House Jagad is yours. Fal Dara is yours."

tʃɪɹz ɹoʊz ɑn ɛvɹi saɪd, kɹæʃɪŋ əɡɛns ðə wɔlz ə ðə kip laɪk bɹeɪkɪŋ weɪvz.

Cheers rose on every side, crashing against the walls of the keep like breaking waves.

ʃɪvɝɪŋ, ɹænd hɝid təwɔɹd ðə dɔɹ tə seɪfti, kɛɹləs ə hum i bʌmpt ɪndə naʊ. dʒʌs jəɹ blʌɾi ɪmædʒəneɪʃən. ʃi dʌzn ivən noʊ hu jə ɑɹ. nɑt jɛt. blʌɾ ən æʃəz, ɪf ʃi dɪd. . . . hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə θɪŋk ʌv wʌt wʊɾə hæpən ɪf ʃi nu hu hi wɑz, wʌɾ i wɑz. wʌt wəd hæpən wən ʃi faɪnəli faʊn aʊt. hi wʌndɝɾ ɪf ʃi hæd hæɾ ɛniθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðə wɪn ətɑp ðə taʊɝ; ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd də θɪŋz laɪk ðæt. wən i pʊʃt θɹu ðət dɔɹ ən slæmd ɪt ʃʌt bɪhaɪn hɪm, mjuɾɪŋ ðə ɹɔɹ ʌv wɛlkəm ðət stɪl ʃʊk ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd, hi hivd ə ɹɪliv saɪ.

Shivering, Rand hurried toward the door to safety, careless of whom he bumped into now. Just your bloody imagination. She doesn't even know who you are. Not yet. Blood and ashes, if she did. . . . He did not want to think of what would have happened if she knew who he was, what he was. What would happen when she finally found out. He wondered if she had had anything to do with the wind atop the tower; Aes Sedai could do things like that. When he pushed through that door and slammed it shut behind him, muting the roar of welcome that still shook the courtyard, he heaved a relieved sigh.

ðə hɔlz hɪɹ wɝ əz ɛmpti əz ði ʌðɝz hæd bɪn, ən i ɔl bʌt ɹæn. aʊɾ əkɹɔs ə smɔlɝ kɔɹtʃjɑɹd, wɪð ə faʊntən splæʃɪŋ ɪn ðə sɛntɝ, daʊn jɛɾ ənʌðɝ kɔɹəɾɝ ən aʊɾ ɪndə ðə flæɡstoʊn steɪbliɑɹd. ðə lɔɹdz steɪbəl ɪtsɛlf, bɪlt ɪndə ðə wɔl ə ðə kip, stʊd tɔl ən lɔŋ, wɪð bɪɡ wɪndoʊz hɪɹ ɪnsaɪd ðə wɔlz, ən hɔɹsəz kɛpt ɑn tu flɔɹz. ðə smɪθi əkɹɔs ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd stʊd saɪlənt, ðə fɛɹiɝ ən ɪz hɛlpɝz ɡɔn tə si ðə wɛlkəm.

The halls here were as empty as the others had been, and he all but ran. Out across a smaller courtyard, with a fountain splashing in the center, down yet another corridor and out into the flagstoned stableyard. The Lord's Stable itself, built into the wall of the keep, stood tall and long, with big windows here inside the walls, and horses kept on two floors. The smithy across the courtyard stood silent, the farrier and his helpers gone to see the Welcome.

timə, ðə lɛðɝi-feɪs hɛd ɡɹum, mɛɾ ɪm ət ðə waɪd dɔɹz wɪð ə dip baʊ, tʌtʃɪŋ ɪz fɔɹhɛɾ ən ðən ɪz hɑɹt. "spɪɹəɾ ən hɑɹt tə sɝv, maɪ lɔɹd. haʊ meɪ timə sɝv, maɪ lɔɹd?" noʊ wɔɹiɝz tɑpnɑt hɪɹ; timəz hɛɹ sæɾ ɑn ɪz hɛd laɪk ən ɪnvɝɾɪd ɡɹeɪ boʊl.

Tema, the leathery-faced head groom, met him at the wide doors with a deep bow, touching his forehead and then his heart. "Spirit and heart to serve, my Lord. How may Tema serve, my Lord?" No warrior's topknot here; Tema's hair sat on his head like an inverted gray bowl.

ɹænd saɪd. "fɔɹ ðə hʌnʒɹədθ taɪm, timə, aɪm nɑɾ ə lɔɹd."

Rand sighed. "For the hundredth time, Tema, I am not a lord."

"æz maɪ lɔɹd wɪʃɪz." ðə ɡɹumz baʊ wɑz ivən loʊɝ ðɪs taɪm.

"As my Lord wishes." The groom's bow was even lower this time.

ɪt wɑz ɪz neɪm ðət kɑz ðə pɹɑbləm, ən ə sɪməlɛɹəɾi. ɹænd ælθɹ. ælən mænʒɹɑɡɔɹən. fəɹ læn, əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ðə kʌstəm ə mɔlkiɝ, ðə ɹɔɪəl "æl" neɪmd ɪm kɪŋ, ðoʊ hi nɛvɝ juzd ɪt hɪmsɛlf. fəɹ ɹænd, "æl" wɑz dʒʌst ə pɑɹɾ ə hɪz neɪm, ðoʊ hi hæd hɝd ðət wʌns, lɔŋ əɡoʊ, bɪfɔɹ ðə tu ɹɪvɝz wɑz kɔl ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, ɪt hæd mɛnt "sʌn ʌv." səm ə ðə sɝvəns ɪn fæl dæɹə kip, ðoʊ, hæd teɪkən ɪt tə min i wɑz ə kɪŋ, tu, əɹ ət list ə pɹɪns. ɔl ə hɪz ɑɹɡjəmən tə ðə kɑntʃɹɛɹi hæɾ oʊnli mænədʒ tə dɪmoʊɾ ɪm tə lɔɹd. ət list, hi θɔɾ ɪt hæd; hi hæd nɛvɝ sin kwaɪt soʊ mʌtʃ boʊɪŋ ən skɹeɪpɪŋ, ivən wɪð lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ.

It was his name that caused the problem, and a similarity. Rand al'Thor. Al'Lan Mandragoran. For Lan, according to the custom of Malkier, the royal "al" named him King, though he never used it himself. For Rand, "al" was just a part of his name, though he had heard that once, long ago, before the Two Rivers was called the Two Rivers, it had meant "son of." Some of the servants in Fal Dara keep, though, had taken it to mean he was a king, too, or at least a prince. All of his argument to the contrary had only managed to demote him to lord. At least, he thought it had; he had never seen quite so much bowing and scraping, even with Lord Agelmar.

"aɪ nid ɹɛd sæɾəld, timə." hi nu bɛɾɝ ðən tə ɔfɝ tə də ɪt hɪmsɛlf; timə wəd nɑt lɛt ɹænd sɔɪl ɪz hænz. "aɪ θɔɾ aɪd spɛn ə fju deɪz siɪŋ ðə kʌntʃɹi ɝaʊn ðə taʊn." wʌns i wɑz ɑn ðə bɪɡ beɪ stæljənz bæk, ə fju deɪz wəd si hɪm ət ðə ɹɪvɝ ɛɹɪnɪn, əɹ əkɹɔs ðə bɔɹɾɝ ɪndə ɝæfəl. ðəl nɛvɝ faɪn mi ðɛn.

"I need Red saddled, Tema." He knew better than to offer to do it himself; Tema would not let Rand soil his hands. "I thought I'd spend a few days seeing the country around the town." Once he was on the big bay stallion's back, a few days would see him at the River Erinin, or across the border into Arafel. They'll never find me then.

ðə ɡɹum bɛn hɪmsɛlf ɔlmoʊs dʌbəl, ən steɪd bɛnt. "fɝɡɪv, maɪ lɔɹd," hi wɪspɝd hɔɹsli. "fɝɡɪv, bʌt timə kænɑɾ oʊbeɪ."

The groom bent himself almost double, and stayed bent. "Forgive, my Lord," he whispered hoarsely. "Forgive, but Tema cannot obey."

flʌʃɪŋ wɪð ɪmbɛɹəsmənt, ɹænd tʊk ən æŋkʃəs lʊk ɝaʊnd - ðəɹ wɑz noʊ wʌn ɛls ɪn saɪt - ðən ɡɹæb ðə mænz ʃoʊldɝ ən pʊld ɪm əpɹaɪt. hi maɪt nɑt bi eɪbəl tə stɑp timə ən ə fju ʌðɝz fɹəm æktɪŋ laɪk ðɪs, bʌɾ i kəd tʃɹaɪ tə stɑp ɛniwʌn ɛls fɹəm siɪŋ ɪt. "waɪ nɑt, timə? timə, lʊk ət mi, pliz. waɪ nɑt?"

Flushing with embarrassment, Rand took an anxious look around - there was no one else in sight - then grabbed the man's shoulder and pulled him upright. He might not be able to stop Tema and a few others from acting like this, but he could try to stop anyone else from seeing it. "Why not, Tema? Tema, look at me, please. Why not?"

"ɪɾ ɪz kəmændəd, maɪ lɔɹd," timə sɛd, stɪl wɪspɝɪŋ. hi kɛp dʒɹɑpɪŋ ɪz aɪz, nɑɾ əfɹeɪd, bʌɾ əʃeɪm ðəɾ i kəd nɑt də wʌt ɹænd æskt. ʃaɪnɝənz tʊk ʃeɪm ðə weɪ ʌðɝ pipəl tʊk biɪŋ bɹændɪɾ ə θif. "noʊ hɔɹs meɪ liv ðɪs steɪbəl əntɪl ði ɔɹɾɝ ɪz tʃeɪnʒd. nɔɹ ɛni steɪbəl ɪn ðə kip, maɪ lɔɹd."

"It is commanded, my Lord," Tema said, still whispering. He kept dropping his eyes, not afraid, but ashamed that he could not do what Rand asked. Shienarans took shame the way other people took being branded a thief. "No horse may leave this stable until the order is changed. Nor any stable in the keep, my Lord."

ɹænd hæɾ ɪz maʊθ oʊpən tə tɛl ðə mæn ɪt wɑz ɔl ɹaɪt, bʌɾ ɪnstɛɾ i lɪkt ɪz lɪps. "noʊ hɔɹs fɹəm ɛni steɪbəl?"

Rand had his mouth open to tell the man it was all right, but instead he licked his lips. "No horse from any stable?"

"jɛs, maɪ lɔɹd. ði ɔɹɾɝ keɪm daʊn oʊnli ə ʃɔɹt taɪm əɡoʊ. oʊnli moʊməns." timəz vɔɪs pɪkt ʌp stʃɹɛŋkθ. "ɔl ðə ɡeɪts ɑɹ kloʊzd əz wɛl, maɪ lɔɹd. nʌn meɪ ɛntɝ əɹ liv wɪθaʊt pɝmɪʃən. nɑɾ ivən ðə sɪɾi pətʃɹoʊl, soʊ timə hæz bɪn toʊld."

"Yes, my Lord. The order came down only a short time ago. Only moments." Tema's voice picked up strength. "All the gates are closed as well, my Lord. None may enter or leave without permission. Not even the city patrol, so Tema has been told."

ɹænd swɑloʊd hɑɹd, bʌɾ ɪt dɪd nɑt lɛsən ðə filɪŋ ə fɪŋɡɝz klʌtʃɪŋ ɪz wɪnpəp. "ði ɔɹɾɝ, timə. ɪt keɪm fɹəm lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ?"

Rand swallowed hard, but it did not lessen the feeling of fingers clutching his windpipe. "The order, Tema. It came from Lord Agelmar?"

"ʌv kɔɹs, maɪ lɔɹd. hu ɛls? lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ dɪd nɑt spik ðə kəmæn tə timə, ʌv kɔɹs, nɔɹ ivən tə ðə mæn u dɪd spik tə timə, bʌt, maɪ lɔɹd, hu ɛls kəd ɡɪv sətʃ ə kəmæn ɪn fæl dæɹə?"

"Of course, my Lord. Who else? Lord Agelmar did not speak the command to Tema, of course, nor even to the man who did speak to Tema, but, my Lord, who else could give such a command in Fal Dara?"

hu ɛls? ɹænd dʒʌmpt əz ðə bɪɡəs bɛl ɪn ðə kip bɛl taʊɝ lɛɾ aʊɾ ə sɑnɝəs pil. ði ʌðɝ bɛlz dʒɔɪn ɪn, ðən bɛlz fɹəm ðə taʊn.

Who else? Rand jumped as the biggest bell in the keep bell tower let out a sonorous peal. The other bells joined in, then bells from the town.

"ɪf timə meɪ bi boʊld," ðə ɡɹum kɔld əbʌv ðə ɹɪvɝbɝeɪʃənz, "maɪ lɔɹd mʌs bi vɛɹi hæpi."

"If Tema may be bold," the groom called above the reverberations, "my Lord must be very happy."

ɹænd hæd tə ʃaʊt bæk tə bi hɝd. "hæpi? waɪ?"

Rand had to shout back to be heard. "Happy? Why?"

"ðə wɛlkəm ɪz fɪnɪʃt, maɪ lɔɹd." timəz dʒɛstʃɝ tʊk ɪn ðə bɛl taʊɝ. "ði æmɪɝlɪn sit wɪl bi sɛndɪŋ fəɹ maɪ lɔɹd, ən maɪ lɔɹdz fɹɛnz, tə kʌm tə hɝ, naʊ."

"The Welcome is finished, my Lord." Tema's gesture took in the bell tower. "The Amyrlin Seat will be sending for my Lord, and my Lord's friends, to come to her, now."

ɹænd bɹoʊk ɪndə ə ɹʌn. hi dʒʌs hæd taɪm tə si ðə sɝpɹaɪz ɑn timəz feɪs, ən ðən i wɑz ɡɔn. hi dɪd nɑt kɛɹ wʌt timə θɔt. ʃɪl bi sɛndɪŋ fəɹ mi naʊ.

Rand broke into a run. He just had time to see the surprise on Tema's face, and then he was gone. He did not care what Tema thought. She will be sending for me now.


tʃæptɝ θɹi


CHAPTER 3

fɹɛnz ən ɛnəmiz


Friends and Enemies

ɹænd dɪd nɑt ɹʌn fɑɹ, oʊnli əz fɑɹ əz ðə sæli ɡeɪɾ ɝaʊn ðə kɔɹnɝ fɹəm ðə steɪbəl. hi sloʊd tə ə wɔk bɪfɔɹ i ɡɑt ðɛɹ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə əpɪɹ kæʒəwəl ən ənhɝid.

Rand did not run far, only as far as the sally gate around the corner from the stable. He slowed to a walk before he got there, trying to appear casual and unhurried.

ði ɑɹtʃt ɡeɪt wɑz kloʊz taɪt. ɪt wɑz bɛɹli bɪɡ ɪnʌf fəɹ tu mɛn tə ɹaɪd θɹu əbɹɛst, bʌt laɪk ɔl ðə ɡeɪts ɪn ði aʊɾɝ wɔl, ɪt wɑz kʌvɝd wɪð bɹɔd stʃɹɪps ə blæk aɪɝn, ən lɑkt ʃʌt wɪð ə θɪk bɑɹ. tu ɡɑɹdz stʊd bɪfɔɹ ðə ɡeɪɾ ɪn pleɪn kɑnɪkəl hɛlməts ən pleɪt-ænd-meɪl ɑɹmɝ, wɪð lɔŋ sɔɹdz ɑn ðɛɹ bæks. ðɛɹ ɡoʊldən sɝkoʊts bɔɹ ðə blæk hɔk ɑn ðə tʃɛst. hi nu wʌn ə ðɛm slaɪtli, ɹeɪɡən. ðə skɑɹ fɹəm ə tʃɹɑlɑk æɹoʊ meɪɾ ə waɪt tʃɹaɪæŋɡəl əɡɛnst ɹeɪɡənz dɑɹk tʃik bɪhaɪn ðə bɑɹz ə hɪz feɪs-ɡɑɹd. ðə pʌkɝd skɪn dɪmpəld wɪð ə ɡɹɪn wən i sɔ ɹænd.

The arched gate was closed tight. It was barely big enough for two men to ride through abreast, but like all the gates in the outer wall, it was covered with broad strips of black iron, and locked shut with a thick bar. Two guards stood before the gate in plain conical helmets and plate-and-mail armor, with long swords on their backs. Their golden surcoats bore the Black Hawk on the chest. He knew one of them slightly, Ragan. The scar from a Trolloc arrow made a white triangle against Ragan's dark cheek behind the bars of his face-guard. The puckered skin dimpled with a grin when he saw Rand.

"pis feɪvɝ ju, ɹænd ælθɹ." ɹeɪɡən ɔlmoʊst ʃaʊɾəd tə bi hɝɾ oʊvɝ ðə bɛlz. "du jə ɪntɛn tə ɡoʊ hɪt ɹæbəts oʊvɝ ðə hɛd, əɹ dʒju stɪl ɪnsɪs ðət klʌb ɪz ə baʊ?" ði ʌðɝ ɡɑɹd ʃɪftəd tə stæn mɔɹ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə ɡeɪt.

"Peace favor you, Rand al'Thor." Ragan almost shouted to be heard over the bells. "Do you intend to go hit rabbits over the head, or do you still insist that club is a bow?" The other guard shifted to stand more in front of the gate.

"pis feɪvɝ ju, ɹeɪɡən," ɹænd sɛd, stɑpɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛm. ɪt wɑz ən ɛfɝt tə kip ɪz vɔɪs kɑm. "ju noʊ ɪts ə baʊ. juv sin mi ʃuɾ ɪt."

"Peace favor you, Ragan," Rand said, stopping in front of them. It was an effort to keep his voice calm. "You know it's a bow. You've seen me shoot it."

"noʊ ɡʊd fɹəm ə hɔɹs," ði ʌðɝ ɡɑɹd sɛd saʊɝli. ɹænd ɹɛkəɡnaɪz hɪm, naʊ, wɪð ɪz dip-sɛt, ɔlmoʊst-blæk aɪz ðət nɛvɝ sim tə blɪŋk. ðeɪ pɪɹd fɹəm ɪz hɛlmət laɪk twɪn keɪvz ɪnsaɪɾ ənʌðɝ keɪv. hi səpoʊz ðəɹ kəd bi wɝs lʌk fəɹ ɪm ðən mæsimə ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə ɡeɪt, bʌɾ i wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ haʊ, ʃɔɹɾ ʌv ə ɹɛɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ. "ɪts tu lɔŋ," mæsimə æɾəd. "aɪ kən ʃut θɹi æɹoʊz wɪð ə hɔɹsboʊ waɪl jə lus wʌn wɪð ðət mɑnstɝ."

"No good from a horse," the other guard said sourly. Rand recognized him, now, with his deep-set, almost-black eyes that never seemed to blink. They peered from his helmet like twin caves inside another cave. He supposed there could be worse luck for him than Masema guarding the gate, but he was not sure how, short of a Red Aes Sedai. "It's too long," Masema added. "I can shoot three arrows with a horsebow while you loose one with that monster."

ɹænd fɔɹst ə ɡɹɪn, əz ɪf i θɔɾ ɪt wɑz ə dʒoʊk. mæsimə hæd nɛvɝ meɪɾ ə dʒoʊk ɪn ɪz hɪɹɪŋ, nɔɹ læft ət wʌn. moʊst ə ðə mɛn ət fæl dæɹə æksɛptɪd ɹænd; hi tʃɹeɪnd wɪð læn, ən lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ hæɾ ɪm ət teɪbəl, ən moʊst ɪmpɔɹɾənt ʌv ɔl, hi hæɾ ɝaɪvd ət fæl dæɹə ɪn kʌmpəni wɪð mɔɪɹeɪn, ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. səm simd əneɪbəl tə fɝɡɛɾ ɪz biɪŋ ən aʊtləndɝ, ðoʊ, bɛɹli seɪɪŋ tu wɝdz tə hɪm, ən ðən oʊnli ɪf ðeɪ hæd tə. mæsimə wɑz ðə wɝst ə ðoʊz.

Rand forced a grin, as if he thought it was a joke. Masema had never made a joke in his hearing, nor laughed at one. Most of the men at Fal Dara accepted Rand; he trained with Lan, and Lord Agelmar had him at table, and most important of all, he had arrived at Fal Dara in company with Moiraine, an Aes Sedai. Some seemed unable to forget his being an outlander, though, barely saying two words to him, and then only if they had to. Masema was the worst of those.

"ɪts ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ mi," ɹænd sɛd. "spikɪŋ ə ɹæbəts, ɹeɪɡən, haʊ əbaʊt lɛɾɪŋ mi aʊt? ɔl ðɪs nɔɪz ən bʌsəl ɪz tu mʌtʃ fəɹ mi. bɛɾɝ tə bi aʊt hʌntɪŋ ɹæbəts, ivən ɪf aɪ nɛvɝ si wʌn."

"It's good enough for me," Rand said. "Speaking of rabbits, Ragan, how about letting me out? All this noise and bustle is too much for me. Better to be out hunting rabbits, even if I never see one."

ɹeɪɡən hæf tɝn tə lʊk əɾ ɪz kəmpænjən, ən ɹændz hoʊps bɪɡæn tə lɪft. ɹeɪɡən wɑz ən iziɡoʊɪŋ mæn, hɪz mænɝ bɪlaɪɪŋ ɪz ɡɹɪm skɑɹ, ən i sim tə laɪk ɹænd. bʌt mæsimə wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd. ɹeɪɡən saɪd. "ɪt kænɑt bi, ɹænd ælθɹ." hi ɡeɪv ə taɪni nɑd təwɔɹd mæsimə əz ɪf tə ɪkspleɪn. ɪf ɪt wɝ ʌp tə hɪm əloʊn. . . . "noʊ wʌn ɪz tə liv wɪθaʊɾ ə ɹɪɾən pæs. tu bæd jə dɪd nɑɾ æsk ə fju mɪnəts əɡoʊ. ðə kəmæn dʒʌs keɪm daʊn tə bɑɹ ðə ɡeɪts."

Ragan half turned to look at his companion, and Rand's hopes began to lift. Ragan was an easygoing man, his manner belying his grim scar, and he seemed to like Rand. But Masema was already shaking his head. Ragan sighed. "It cannot be, Rand al'Thor." He gave a tiny nod toward Masema as if to explain. If it were up to him alone. . . . "No one is to leave without a written pass. Too bad you did not ask a few minutes ago. The command just came down to bar the gates."

"bʌt waɪ wəd lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ wɑnə kip mi ɪn?" mæsimə wɑz aɪɪŋ ðə bʌndəlz ɑn ɹændz bæk, ən ɪz sæɾəlbæɡz. ɹænd tʃɹaɪd tə ɪɡnɔɹ hɪm. "ɪm ɪz ɡɛst," hi wɛn ɑn tə ɹeɪɡən. "baɪ maɪ ɑnɝ, aɪ cʊɾə lɛft ɛnitaɪm ðiz pæst wiks. waɪ wəɾ i min ðɪs ɔɹɾɝ fəɹ mi? ɪts lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝz ɔɹɾɝ, ɪzən ɪt?" mæsimə blɪŋkt ət ðæt, ən ɪz pɝpɛtʃuəl fɹaʊn dipənd; hi ɔlmoʊst əpɪɹd tə fɝɡɛt ɹændz pæks.

"But why would Lord Agelmar want to keep me in?" Masema was eyeing the bundles on Rand's back, and his saddlebags. Rand tried to ignore him. "I'm his guest," he went on to Ragan. "By my honor, I could have left anytime these past weeks. Why would he mean this order for me? It is Lord Agelmar's order, isn't it?" Masema blinked at that, and his perpetual frown deepened; he almost appeared to forget Rand's packs.

ɹeɪɡən læft. "hu ɛls kəd ɡɪv sətʃ ən ɔɹɾɝ, ɹænd ælθɹ? ʌv kɔɹs, ɪt wɑz ənoʊ hu pæst ɪt tə mi, bʌt huz ɔɹɾɝ kəɾ ɪɾ əv bɪn?"

Ragan laughed. "Who else could give such an order, Rand al'Thor? Of course, it was Uno who passed it to me, but whose order could it have been?"

mæsiməz aɪz, fɪkst ɑn ɹændz feɪs, dɪd nɑt blɪŋk. "aɪ dʒʌst wɑnə ɡoʊ aʊt baɪ maɪsɛlf, ðæts ɔl," ɹænd sɛd. "aɪl tʃɹaɪ wʌn ə ðə ɡɑɹɾənz, ðɛn. noʊ ɹæbəts, bʌɾ ət lis ðəɹ woʊn bi ə kɹaʊd. ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin ju, ən pis feɪvɝ ju."

Masema's eyes, fixed on Rand's face, did not blink. "I just want to go out by myself, that's all," Rand said. "I'll try one of the gardens, then. No rabbits, but at least there won't be a crowd. The Light illumine you, and peace favor you."

hi wɔkt əweɪ wɪθaʊt weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ən ænsɝɪŋ blɛsɪŋ, ɹizɑlvɪŋ nɑt tə ɡoʊ nɪɹ ɛni ʌv ðə ɡɑɹɾənz ɑn ɛni əkaʊnt. bɝn mi, wʌns ðə sɛɹəmoʊniz ɑɹ dʌn ðəɹ kəd bi ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ɛni ʌv ðɛm. əwɛɹ ə mæsiməz aɪz ɑn ɪz bæk - hi wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz mæsimə - hi kɛpt ɪz peɪs nɔɹməl.

He walked away without waiting for an answering blessing, resolving not to go near any of the gardens on any account. Burn me, once the ceremonies are done there could be Aes Sedai in any of them. Aware of Masema's eyes on his back - he was sure it was Masema - he kept his pace normal.

sʌɾənli ðə bɛlz stɑpt ɹɪŋɪŋ, ən i skɪpt ə stɛp. mɪnəts wɝ pæsɪŋ. ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni ʌv ðɛm. taɪm fəɹ ði æmɪɝlɪn sit tə bi ʃoʊn tə hɝ tʃeɪmbɝz. taɪm fəɹ əɹ tə sɛn fəɹ hɪm, tə stɑɹɾ ə sɝtʃ wən i wɑz nɑt faʊnd. əz sun əz i wɑz aʊɾ ə saɪɾ ə ðə sæli ɡeɪt, hi bɪɡæn tə ɹʌn əɡɛn.

Suddenly the bells stopped ringing, and he skipped a step. Minutes were passing. A great many of them. Time for the Amyrlin Seat to be shown to her chambers. Time for her to send for him, to start a search when he was not found. As soon as he was out of sight of the sally gate, he began to run again.

nɪɹ ðə bæɹəks' kɪtʃənz, ðə kɑɹɾɝz' ɡeɪt, wɛɹ ɔl ðə fudstʌfs fəɹ ðə kip wɝ bɹɔɾ ɪn, stʊd kloʊzd ən bɑɹd, bɪhaɪn ə pɛɹ ə soʊlʒɝz. hi hɝid pæst, əkɹɔs ðə kɪtʃən jɑɹd, əz ɪf i hæd nɛvɝ mɛn tə stɑp.

Near the barracks' kitchens, the Carters' Gate, where all the foodstuffs for the keep were brought in, stood closed and barred, behind a pair of soldiers. He hurried past, across the kitchen yard, as if he had never meant to stop.

ðə dɔɡ ɡeɪt, ət ðə bæk ə ðə kip, dʒʌs haɪ ɪnʌf ən waɪɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ wʌn mæn ɑn fʊt, hæɾ ɪts ɡɑɹdz, tu. hi tɝn ɝaʊn bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ sɔ hɪm. ðəɹ wɝ nɑt mɛni ɡeɪts, ivən əz bɪɡ əz ðə kip wɑz, bʌɾ ɪf ðə dɔɡ ɡeɪt wɑz ɡɑɹɾəd, ðeɪ ɔl wəd bi.

The Dog Gate, at the back of the keep, just high enough and wide enough for one man on foot, had its guards, too. He turned around before they saw him. There were not many gates, even as big as the keep was, but if the Dog Gate was guarded, they all would be.

pɝhæps i kəd faɪn ə lɛŋθ ə ɹoʊp. . . . hi klaɪmd wʌn ə ðə stɛɹz tə ðə tɑp ə ði aʊɾɝ wɔl, tə ðə waɪd pɛɹəpət wɪð ɪts kɹɛnɛleɪɾɪd wɔlz. ɪt wɑz nɑt kʌmftəɹbəl fəɹ hɪm, biɪŋ soʊ haɪ ən ɪkspoʊzd ɪf ðət wɪn keɪm əɡɛn, bʌt fɹəm ðəɹ i kəd si əkɹɔs ðə tɔl tʃɪmniz ən ʃɑɹp ɹufs ə ðə taʊn ɔl ðə weɪ tə ðə sɪɾi wɔl. ivən æftɝ nɪɹli ə mʌnθ, ðə haʊsəz stɪl lʊkt ɑd tə hɪz tu ɹɪvɝz aɪz, ivz ɹitʃɪŋ ɔlmoʊs tə ðə ɡɹaʊn əz ɪf ðə haʊsəz wɝ ɔl wʊd-ʃɪŋɡəld ɹuf, ən tʃɪmniz æŋɡəl tə lɛt hɛvi snoʊ slaɪd pæst. ə bɹɔd, peɪv skwɛɹ sɝaʊndəd ðə kip, bʌɾ oʊnli ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz fɹəm ðə wɔl leɪ stʃɹits fʊl ə pipəl ɡoʊɪŋ əbaʊt ðɛɹ deɪli bɪznəs, eɪpɹənd ʃɑpkipɝz aʊɾ ʌndɝ ði ɔnɪŋz ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛɹ ʃɑps, ɹʌf-kloʊð fɑɹmɝz ɪn taʊn tə baɪ ən sɛl, hɔkɝz ən tʃɹeɪdzmən ən taʊnzpipəl ɡæðɝɾ ɪn nɑts, noʊ daʊt tə tɔk əbaʊt ðə sɝpɹaɪz vɪzət fɹəm ði æmɪɝlɪn sit. hi kəd si kɑɹts ən pipəl floʊɪŋ θɹu wʌn ə ðə ɡeɪts ɪn ðə taʊn wɔl. əpɛɹənli ðə ɡɑɹdz ðəɹ hæd noʊ ɔɹɾɝz əbaʊt stɑpɪŋ ɛniwʌn.

Perhaps he could find a length of rope. . . . He climbed one of the stairs to the top of the outer wall, to the wide parapet with its crenellated walls. It was not comfortable for him, being so high and exposed if that wind came again, but from there he could see across the tall chimneys and sharp roofs of the town all the way to the city wall. Even after nearly a month, the houses still looked odd to his Two Rivers eyes, eaves reaching almost to the ground as if the houses were all wood-shingled roof, and chimneys angled to let heavy snow slide past. A broad, paved square surrounded the keep, but only a hundred paces from the wall lay streets full of people going about their daily business, aproned shopkeepers out under the awnings in front of their shops, rough-clothed farmers in town to buy and sell, hawkers and tradesmen and townspeople gathered in knots, no doubt to talk about the surprise visit from the Amyrlin Seat. He could see carts and people flowing through one of the gates in the town wall. Apparently the guards there had no orders about stopping anyone.

hi lʊkt ʌp ət ðə nɪɹəst ɡɑɹtaʊɝ; wʌn ə ðə soʊlʒɝz ɹeɪzd ə ɡɔntələɾəd hæn tə hɪm. wɪð ə bɪɾɝ læf, hi weɪv bæk. nɑɾ ə fʊɾ ə ðə wɔl bʌt wɑz ʌndɝ ði aɪz ʌv ɡɑɹdz. linɪŋ θɹu ən ɛmbɹəʒɝ, hi pɪɹd daʊn pæs ðə slɑts ɪn ðə stoʊn fəɹ sɛɾɪŋ hɔɹɾɪŋz, daʊn ðə ʃɪɹ ɪkspæns ə stoʊn tə ðə dʒɹaɪmoʊt fɑɹ bɪloʊ. twɛnti peɪsɪz waɪɾ ən tɛn dip, feɪst wɪð stoʊn pɑlɪʃt slɪpɝi smuð. ə loʊ wɔl, slæntəd tə ɡɪv noʊ haɪɾɪŋ pleɪs, sɝaʊndəɾ ɪt tə kip ɛniwʌn fɹəm fɔlɪŋ ɪn baɪ æksəɾənt, ən ɪts bɑɾəm wɑz ə fɔɹəst ə ɹeɪzɝ-ʃɑɹp spaɪks. ivən wɪð ə ɹoʊp tə klaɪm daʊn ən noʊ ɡɑɹdz wɑtʃɪŋ, hi kəd nɑt kɹɔs ðæt. wʌt sɝv tə kip tʃɹɑləks aʊɾ ɪn ðə læst ɪkstʃɹim sɝv dʒʌst əz wɛl tə kip ɪm ɪn.

He looked up at the nearest guardtower; one of the soldiers raised a gauntleted hand to him. With a bitter laugh, he waved back. Not a foot of the wall but was under the eyes of guards. Leaning through an embrasure, he peered down past the slots in the stone for setting hoardings, down the sheer expanse of stone to the drymoat far below. Twenty paces wide and ten deep, faced with stone polished slippery smooth. A low wall, slanted to give no hiding place, surrounded it to keep anyone from falling in by accident, and its bottom was a forest of razor-sharp spikes. Even with a rope to climb down and no guards watching, he could not cross that. What served to keep Trollocs out in the last extreme served just as well to keep him in.

sʌɾənli hi fɛlt wɪɹi tə ðə boʊn, dʒɹeɪnd. ði æmɪɝlɪn sit wɑz ðɛɹ, ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ aʊt. noʊ weɪ aʊt, ən ði æmɪɝlɪn sit ðɛɹ. ɪf ʃi nu hi wɑz ðɛɹ, ɪf ʃi hæd sɛn ðə wɪn ðət hæd siz hɪm, ðən ʃi wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi hʌntɪŋ hɪm, hʌntɪŋ wɪð ən ɛɛs sədaɪz paʊɝz. ɹæbəts hæd mɔɹ tʃæns əɡɛnst ɪz baʊ. hi ɹəfjuz tə ɡɪv ʌp, ðoʊ. ðəɹ wɝ ðoʊz u sɛd tu ɹɪvɝz foʊk kəd titʃ stoʊnz ən ɡɪv lɛsənz tə mjulz. wən ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ ɛls lɛft, tu ɹɪvɝz pipəl hʌŋ ɑn tə ðɛɹ stʌbɝnnəs.

Suddenly he felt weary to the bone, drained. The Amyrlin Seat was there, and there was no way out. No way out, and the Amyrlin Seat there. If she knew he was there, if she had sent the wind that had seized him, then she was already hunting him, hunting with an Aes Sedai's powers. Rabbits had more chance against his bow. He refused to give up, though. There were those who said Two Rivers folk could teach stones and give lessons to mules. When there was nothing else left, Two Rivers people hung on to their stubbornness.

livɪŋ ðə wɔl, hi wɑndɝd θɹu ðə kip. hi peɪd noʊ maɪn tə wɛɹ i wɛnt, soʊ lɔŋ əz ɪt wɑz noʊwɛɹ i wəd bi ɪkspɛktəd. nɑɾ ɛniwɛɹ nɪɹ ɪz ɹum, nɔɹ ɛni ʌv ðə steɪbəlz, nɔɹ ɛni ɡeɪt - mæsimə maɪt ɹɪsk ənoʊz tʌŋ tə ɹipɔɹɾ ɪm tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə liv - nɔɹ ɡɑɹɾən. ɔl i kəd θɪŋk ʌv wɑz kipɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ. ivən mɔɪɹeɪn. ʃi nu əbaʊt hɪm. dɪspaɪt ðæt, ʃi hæd dʌn nʌθɪŋ əɡɛns hɪm. soʊ fɑɹ. soʊ fɑɹ əz jə noʊ. wʌɾ ɪf ʃiz tʃeɪnʒd əɹ maɪnd? meɪbi ʃi sɛn fəɹ ði æmɪɝlɪn sit.

Leaving the wall, he wandered through the keep. He paid no mind to where he went, so long as it was nowhere he would be expected. Not anywhere near his room, nor any of the stables, nor any gate - Masema might risk Uno's tongue to report him trying to leave - nor garden. All he could think of was keeping away from any Aes Sedai. Even Moiraine. She knew about him. Despite that, she had done nothing against him. So far. So far as you know. What if she's changed her mind? Maybe she sent for the Amyrlin Seat.
