fəɹ ə moʊmənt, filɪŋ lɔst, hi lin əɡɛns ðə kɔɹəɾɝ wɔl, ðə stoʊn hɑɹɾ ʌndɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. aɪz blæŋk, hi stɛɹɾ əɾ ə dɪstənt nʌθɪŋ ən sɔ θɪŋz i dɪd nɑt wɑnə si. dʒɛntəld. wəɾ ɪt bi soʊ bæd, tə hæv ɪɾ ɔl oʊvɝ? ɹɪli oʊvɝ? hi kloʊzd ɪz aɪz, bʌɾ i kəd stɪl si hɪmsɛlf, hʌɾəlɪŋ laɪk ə ɹæbət wɪð noʊwɛɹ lɛf tə ɹʌn, ən ɛɛs sədaɪ kloʊzɪŋ ɹaʊn ɪm laɪk ɹeɪvənz. ðeɪ ɔlmoʊst ɔlweɪz daɪ sun æftɝ, mɛn huv bɪn dʒɛntəld. ðeɪ stɑp wɑntɪŋ tə lɪv. hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd tɑm mɛɹɪlɪnz wɝdz tu wɛl tə feɪs ðæt. wɪð ə bɹɪsk ʃeɪk, hi hɝiɾ ɑn daʊn ðə hɔl. noʊ nid tə steɪ ɪn wʌn pleɪs əntɪl i wɑz faʊnd. haʊ lɔŋ tɪl ðeɪ faɪn jə ɛniweɪ? jəɹ laɪk ə ʃip ɪn ə pɛn. haʊ lɔŋ? hi tʌtʃt ðə sɔɹd hɪlt əɾ ɪz saɪd. noʊ, nɑɾ ə ʃip. nɑt fəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ əɹ ɛnibəɾi ɛls. hi fɛlt ə lɪɾəl fulɪʃ, bʌt dɪtɝmənd.

For a moment, feeling lost, he leaned against the corridor wall, the stone hard under his shoulder. Eyes blank, he stared at a distant nothing and saw things he did not want to see. Gentled. Would it be so bad, to have it all over? Really over? He closed his eyes, but he could still see himself, huddling like a rabbit with nowhere left to run, and Aes Sedai closing round him like ravens. They almost always die soon after, men who've been gentled. They stop wanting to live. He remembered Thom Merrilin's words too well to face that. With a brisk shake, he hurried on down the hall. No need to stay in one place until he was found. How long till they find you anyway? You're like a sheep in a pen. How long? He touched the sword hilt at his side. No, not a sheep. Not for Aes Sedai or anybody else. He felt a little foolish, but determined.

pipəl wɝ ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə ðɛɹ tæsks. ə dɪn ə vɔɪsəz ən klæɾɝɪŋ pɑts fɪl ðə kɪtʃən ðət leɪ nɪɹəs ðə ɡɹeɪt hɔl, wɛɹ ði æmɪɝlɪn siɾ ən əɹ pɑɹɾi wəd fis ðət naɪt. kʊks ən skʌljənz ən pɑtbɔɪz ɔl bʌt ɹæn ət ðɛɹ wɝk; ðə spɪt dɑɡz tʃɹɑɾəd ɪn ðɛɹ wɪkɝ wilz tə tɝn ðə spɪɾɪd mits. hi meɪɾ ɪz weɪ kwɪkli θɹu ðə hiɾ ən stim, θɹu ðə smɛlz ə spaɪsəz ən kʊkɪŋ. noʊ wʌn spɛɹɾ ɪm ə sɛkənd ɡlæns; ðeɪ wɝ ɔl tu bɪzi.

People were returning to their tasks. A din of voices and clattering pots filled the kitchen that lay nearest the Great Hall, where the Amyrlin Seat and her party would feast that night. Cooks and scullions and potboys all but ran at their work; the spit dogs trotted in their wicker wheels to turn the spitted meats. He made his way quickly through the heat and steam, through the smells of spices and cooking. No one spared him a second glance; they were all too busy.

ðə bæk hɔlz, wɛɹ ðə sɝvəns lɪvd ɪn smɔl əpɑɹtməns, wɝ stɝɪŋ laɪk ə kɪkt ænθip əz mɛn ən wɪmən skɝid tə dɑn ðɛɹ bɛs lɪvɝi. tʃɪlʒɹən dɪd ðɛɹ pleɪɪŋ ɪn kɔɹnɝz, aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ. bɔɪz weɪvd wʊɾən sɔɹdz, ən ɡɝlz pleɪd wɪð kɑɹv dɑlz, səm ənaʊnsɪŋ ðət hɝz wɑz ði æmɪɝlɪn sit. moʊst ə ðə dɔɹz stʊɾ oʊpən, dɔɹweɪz blɑkt oʊnli baɪ biɾɪd kɝɾənz. nɔɹməli, ðət mɛn huɛvɝ lɪv ðəɹ wɑz oʊpən tə vɪzəɾɝz, bʌt tədeɪ ɪt sɪmpli mɛn ðə ɹɛzəɾənts wɝ ɪn ə hɝi. ivən ðoʊz u baʊd tə hɪm dɪd soʊ wɪð hɑɹdli ə pɔz.

The back halls, where the servants lived in small apartments, were stirring like a kicked antheap as men and women scurried to don their best livery. Children did their playing in corners, out of the way. Boys waved wooden swords, and girls played with carved dolls, some announcing that hers was the Amyrlin Seat. Most of the doors stood open, doorways blocked only by beaded curtains. Normally, that meant whoever lived there was open to visitors, but today it simply meant the residents were in a hurry. Even those who bowed to him did so with hardly a pause.

wəɾ ɛni ʌv əm hɪɹ, wən ðeɪ wɛn tə sɝv, ðəɾ i wɑz biɪŋ sɔt, ən spik ə siɪŋ hɪm? spik tə ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ən tɛl əɹ wɛɹ tə faɪn hɪm? ði aɪz ðəɾ i pæst sʌɾənli əpɪɹd tə bi stʌɾiɪŋ ɪm slaɪli, ən tə bi weɪɪŋ ən kənsɪɾɝɪŋ bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk. ivən ðə tʃɪlʒɹən tʊk ɑn ʃɑɹpɝ lʊks ɪn ɪz maɪnz aɪ. hi nu ɪt wɑz dʒʌst ɪz ɪmædʒəneɪʃən - hi wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz; ɪt hæd tə bi - bʌt wən ðə sɝvəns' əpɑɹtməns wɝ bɪhaɪn hɪm, hi fɛlt əz ɪf i hæɾ ɪskeɪp bɪfɔɹ ə tʃɹæp kəd spɹɪŋ ʃʌt.

Would any of them hear, when they went to serve, that he was being sought, and speak of seeing him? Speak to an Aes Sedai and tell her where to find him? The eyes that he passed suddenly appeared to be studying him slyly, and to be weighing and considering behind his back. Even the children took on sharper looks in his mind's eye. He knew it was just his imagination - he was sure it was; it had to be - but when the servants' apartments were behind him, he felt as if he had escaped before a trap could spring shut.

səm pleɪsəz ɪn ðə kip wɝ ɛmpti ʌv pipəl, ðə foʊk u nɔɹməli wɝk ðəɹ ɹilis fəɹ ðə sʌɾən hɑlədeɪ. ði ɑɹmɔɹɝz fɔɹdʒ, wɪð ɔl ðə faɪɝz bæŋkt, ði ænvəlz saɪlənt. saɪlənt. koʊld. laɪfləs. jɛt sʌmhaʊ nɑɾ ɛmpti. hɪz skɪn pɹɪkəld, ən i spʌn ɑn ɪz hil. noʊ wʌn ðɛɹ. dʒʌs ðə bɪɡ skwɛɹ tul tʃɛsts ən ðə kwɛntʃɪŋ bæɹəlz fʊl ʌv ɔɪl. ðə hɛɹ ɑn ðə bæk ə hɪz nɛk stɝd, ən i wɪpt ɹaʊn əɡɛn. ðə hæmɝz ən tɑŋz hʌŋ ɪn ðɛɹ pleɪsəz ɑn ðə wɔl. æŋɡɹəli hi stɛɹɾ ɝaʊn ðə bɪɡ ɹum. ðɛɹz noʊbɑdi ðɛɹ. ɪts dʒʌs maɪ ɪmædʒəneɪʃən. ðət wɪnd, ən ði æmɪɝlɪn; ðæts ɪnʌf tə meɪk mi ɪmædʒən θɪŋz.

Some places in the keep were empty of people, the folk who normally worked there released for the sudden holiday. The armorer's forge, with all the fires banked, the anvils silent. Silent. Cold. Lifeless. Yet somehow not empty. His skin prickled, and he spun on his heel. No one there. Just the big square tool chests and the quenching barrels full of oil. The hair on the back of his neck stirred, and he whipped round again. The hammers and tongs hung in their places on the wall. Angrily he stared around the big room. There's nobody there. It's just my imagination. That wind, and the Amyrlin; that's enough to make me imagine things.

aʊtsaɪɾ ɪn ði ɑɹmɔɹɝz jɑɹd, ðə wɪn swɝld ʌp ɝaʊn ɪm moʊməntɛɹəli. dɪspaɪt hɪmsɛlf i dʒʌmpt, θɪŋkɪŋ ɪt mɛn tə kætʃ hɪm. fəɹ ə moʊmən i smɛl ðə feɪn oʊɾɝ ə dəkeɪ əɡɛn, ən hɝd sʌmwʌn bɪhaɪn ɪm læfɪŋ slaɪli. dʒʌs fəɹ ə moʊmənt. fɹaɪɾənd, hi ɛdʒd ɪn ə sɝkəl, piɹɪŋ wɛɹəli. ðə jɑɹd, peɪvd wɪð ɹʌf stoʊn, wɑz ɛmpti ɪksɛp fəɹ hɪm. dʒʌs jəɹ blʌɾi ɪmædʒəneɪʃən! hi ɹæn ɛniweɪ, ən bɪhaɪn ɪm i θɔɾ i hɝd ðə læftɝ əɡɛn, ðɪs taɪm wɪθaʊt ðə wɪnd.

Outside in the armorer's yard, the wind swirled up around him momentarily. Despite himself he jumped, thinking it meant to catch him. For a moment he smelled the faint odor of decay again, and heard someone behind him laughing slyly. Just for a moment. Frightened, he edged in a circle, peering warily. The yard, paved with rough stone, was empty except for him. Just your bloody imagination! He ran anyway, and behind him he thought he heard the laughter again, this time without the wind.

ɪn ðə wʊdʒjɑɹd, ðə pɹɛzəns ɹɪtɝnd, ðə sɛns ə sʌmwʌn ðɛɹ. ðə fil ʌv aɪz piɹɪŋ əɾ ɪm ɝaʊn tɔl paɪlz ə splɪt faɪɝwʊɾ ʌndɝ ðə lɔŋ ʃɛdz, dɑɹɾɪŋ ɡlænsɪz oʊvɝ ðə stæks ə sizən plæŋks ən tɪmbɝz weɪɾɪŋ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə jɑɹd fəɹ ðə kɑɹpəntɝz ʃɑp, naʊ kloʊzd ʌp taɪt. hi ɹəfjuz tə lʊk ɝaʊnd, ɹəfjuz tə θɪŋk ə haʊ wʌn sɛɾ ʌv aɪz kəd muv fɹəm pleɪs tə pleɪs soʊ fæst, kəd kɹɔs ði oʊpən jɑɹd fɹəm ðə faɪɝwʊd ʃɛd tə ðə lʌmɝʃɛt wɪθaʊɾ ivən ə flɪkɝ ə muvmən ðəɾ i kəd si. hi wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz wʌn sɛɾ ʌv aɪz. ɪmædʒəneɪʃən. əɹ meɪbi aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ kɹeɪzi ɔlɹɛɾi. hi ʃɪvɝd. nɑt jɛt. laɪt, pliz nɑt jɛt. stɪf-bækt, hi stɔkt əkɹɔs ðə wʊdʒjɑɹd, ən ði ənsin wɑtʃɝ fɑloʊd.

In the woodyard, the presence returned, the sense of someone there. The feel of eyes peering at him around tall piles of split firewood under the long sheds, darting glances over the stacks of seasoned planks and timbers waiting on the other side of the yard for the carpenter's shop, now closed up tight. He refused to look around, refused to think of how one set of eyes could move from place to place so fast, could cross the open yard from the firewood shed to the lumbershed without even a flicker of movement that he could see. He was sure it was one set of eyes. Imagination. Or maybe I'm going crazy already. He shivered. Not yet. Light, please not yet. Stiff-backed, he stalked across the woodyard, and the unseen watcher followed.

daʊn dip kɔɹɪɾɝz lɪɾ oʊnli baɪ ə fju ɹʌʃ tɔɹtʃɪz, ɪn stɔɹɹumz fɪld wɪð sæks ə dʒɹaɪd piz əɹ binz, kɹaʊɾəd wɪð slæɾɪd ɹæks hipt wɪð ɹɪŋkəl tɝnəps ən bits, əɹ stækt wɪð bæɹəlz ʌv waɪn ən kæsks ə sɔltəd bif ən kɛɡz ʌv eɪl, ði aɪz wɝ ɔlweɪz ðɛɹ, səmtaɪmz fɑloʊɪŋ hɪm, səmtaɪmz weɪɾɪŋ wən i ɛntɝd. hi nɛvɝ hɝɾ ə fʊtstɛp bʌɾ ɪz oʊn, nɛvɝ hɝɾ ə dɔɹ kɹik ɪksɛpt wən i oʊpən ən kloʊzd ɪt, bʌt ði aɪz wɝ ðɛɹ. laɪt, aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ kɹeɪzi.

Down deep corridors lit only by a few rush torches, in storerooms filled with sacks of dried peas or beans, crowded with slatted racks heaped with wrinkled turnips and beets, or stacked with barrels of wine and casks of salted beef and kegs of ale, the eyes were always there, sometimes following him, sometimes waiting when he entered. He never heard a footstep but his own, never heard a door creak except when he opened and closed it, but the eyes were there. Light, I am going crazy.

ðən i oʊpən ənʌðɝ stɔɹɹum dɔɹ, ən hjumən vɔɪsəz, hjumən læftɝ, dʒɹɪftəɾ aʊt tə fɪl ɪm wɪð ɹɪlif. ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ ənsin aɪ hɪɹ. hi wɛn ɪn.

Then he opened another storeroom door, and human voices, human laughter, drifted out to fill him with relief. There would be no unseen eye here. He went in.

hæf ðə ɹum wɑz stæk tə ðə silɪŋ wɪð sæks ʌv ɡɹeɪn. ɪn ði ʌðɝ hæf ə θɪk sɛmɪsɝkəl ə mɛn nɛlt ɪn fɹʌn ʌv wʌn ə ðə bɛɹ wɔlz. ðeɪ ɔl sim tə wɛɹ ðə lɛðɝ dʒɝkɪnz ən boʊl-kʌt hɛɹ ə minaɪəlz. noʊ wɔɹiɝz' tɑpnɑts, noʊ lɪvɝi. noʊ wʌn u maɪt bɪtʃɹeɪ hɪm æksədɛntəli. wʌɾ əbaʊɾ ɑn pɝpəs? ðə ɹæɾəl ə daɪs keɪm θɹu ðɛɹ sɑf mɝmɝz, ən sʌmbɑɾi lɛɾ aʊɾ ə ɹɔkəs læf ət ðə θɹoʊ.

Half the room was stacked to the ceiling with sacks of grain. In the other half a thick semicircle of men knelt in front of one of the bare walls. They all seemed to wear the leather jerkins and bowl-cut hair of menials. No warriors' topknots, no livery. No one who might betray him accidentally. What about on purpose? The rattle of dice came through their soft murmurs, and somebody let out a raucous laugh at the throw.

lɔɪəl wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ əm daɪs, ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz tʃɪn θɔtfəli wɪð ə fɪŋɡɝ θɪkɝ ðən ə bɪɡ mænz θʌm, hɪz hɛɾ ɔlmoʊst ɹitʃɪŋ ðə ɹæftɝz nɪɹli tu spænz ʌp. nʌn ə ðə dɪsɝz ɡeɪv ɪm ə ɡlæns. oʊɡiɝ wɝ nɑɾ ɪɡzækli kɑmən ɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz, əɹ ɛniwɛɹ ɛls, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ noʊn ən æksɛptɪd hɪɹ, ən lɔɪəl hæd bɪn ɪn fæl dæɹə lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə ɪksaɪt lɪɾəl kɑmɛnt. ði oʊɡiɝz dɑɹk, stɪf-kɑlɝd tunɪk wɑz bʌɾənd ʌp tə hɪz nɛk ən flɛɹd bɪloʊ ðə weɪst oʊvɝ ɪz haɪ buts, ən wʌn ə ðə bɪɡ pɑkəts bʌlʒd ən sæɡd wɪð ðə weɪɾ ə sʌmθɪŋ. bʊks, ɪf ɹænd nu hɪm. ivən wɑtʃɪŋ mɛn ɡæmbəl, lɔɪəl wəd nɑt bi fɑɹ fɹəm ə bʊk.

Loial was watching them dice, rubbing his chin thoughtfully with a finger thicker than a big man's thumb, his head almost reaching the rafters nearly two spans up. None of the dicers gave him a glance. Ogier were not exactly common in the Borderlands, or anywhere else, but they were known and accepted here, and Loial had been in Fal Dara long enough to excite little comment. The Ogier's dark, stiff-collared tunic was buttoned up to his neck and flared below the waist over his high boots, and one of the big pockets bulged and sagged with the weight of something. Books, if Rand knew him. Even watching men gamble, Loial would not be far from a book.

ɪn spaɪɾ ʌv ɛvɹiθɪŋ, ɹænd faʊn hɪmsɛlf ɡɹɪnɪŋ. lɔɪəl ɔfən hæd ðəɾ ɪfɛkt ɑn hɪm. ði oʊɡiɝ nu soʊ mʌtʃ əbaʊt səm θɪŋz, soʊ lɪɾəl əbaʊɾ ʌðɝz, ən i sim tə wɑnə noʊ ɛvɹiθɪŋ. jɛt ɹænd kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə fɝs taɪm i ɛvɝ sɔ lɔɪəl, wɪð ɪz tʌftəɾ ɪɹz ən ɪz aɪbɹaʊz ðət dæŋɡəld laɪk lɔŋ mʌstæʃɪz ən ɪz noʊz ɔlmoʊst əz waɪɾ əz ɪz feɪs - sɔ hɪm ən θɔɾ i wɑz feɪsɪŋ ə tʃɹɑlɑk. ɪt stɪl ʃeɪm hɪm. oʊɡiɝ ən tʃɹɑləks. mɹdʒɹɑl, ən θɪŋz fɹəm ðə dɑɹk kɔɹnɝz ə mɪdnaɪt teɪlz. θɪŋz aʊɾ ə stɔɹiz ən lɛdʒənz. ðət wɑz haʊ hi hæd θɔɾ ə ðɛm bɪfɔɹ i lɛft ɛmənz fild. bʌt sɪns livɪŋ hoʊm i hæd sin tu mɛni stɔɹiz wɔkɪŋ ɪn ðə flɛʃ ɛvɝ tə bi soʊ ʃʊɹ əɡɛn. ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən ənsin wɑtʃɝz, ən ə wɪn ðət kɑɾ ən hɛld. hɪz smaɪl feɪɾəd.

In spite of everything, Rand found himself grinning. Loial often had that effect on him. The Ogier knew so much about some things, so little about others, and he seemed to want to know everything. Yet Rand could remember the first time he ever saw Loial, with his tufted ears and his eyebrows that dangled like long mustaches and his nose almost as wide as his face - saw him and thought he was facing a Trolloc. It still shamed him. Ogier and Trollocs. Myrddraal, and things from the dark corners of midnight tales. Things out of stories and legends. That was how he had thought of them before he left Emond's Field. But since leaving home he had seen too many stories walking in the flesh ever to be so sure again. Aes Sedai, and unseen watchers, and a wind that caught and held. His smile faded.

"ɔl ðə stɔɹiz ɑɹ ɹil," hi sɛd sɔfli.

"All the stories are real," he said softly.

lɔɪəlz ɪɹz twɪtʃt, ən ɪz hɛd tɝn təwɔɹd ɹænd. wən i sɔ hu ɪt wɑz, ði oʊɡiɝz feɪs splɪɾ ɪn ə ɡɹɪn, ən i keɪm oʊvɝ. "ɑ, ðəɹ jə ɑɹ." hɪz vɔɪs wɑz ə dip bʌmbəlɪbi ɹʌmbəl. "aɪ dɪd nɑt si jə ət ðə wɛlkəm. ðət wɑz sʌmθɪŋ aɪ hæd nɑt sin bɪfɔɹ. tu θɪŋz. ðə ʃaɪnɝən wɛlkəm, ən ði æmɪɝlɪn sit. ʃi lʊks taɪɝd, doʊn jə θɪŋk? ɪt kænɑt bi izi, biɪŋ æmɪɝlɪn. wɝs ðən biɪŋ ən ɛldɝ, aɪ səpoʊz." hi pɔzd, wɪð ə θɔtfəl lʊk, bʌɾ oʊnli fəɹ ə bɹɛθ. "tɛl mi, ɹænd, dʒju pleɪ ət daɪs, tu? ðeɪ pleɪ ə sɪmpəlɝ ɡeɪm hɪɹ, wɪð oʊnli θɹi daɪs. wi juz fɔɹ ɪn ðə stɛɾɪŋ. ðeɪ woʊn lemi pleɪ, jə noʊ. ðeɪ dʒʌst seɪ, 'ɡlɔɹi tə ðə bɪldɝz,' ən wɪl nɑt bɛɾ əɡɛns mi. aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðæts fɛɹ, də ju? ðə daɪs ðeɪ jus ɑɹ ɹæðɝ smɔl" - hi fɹaʊn ət wʌn ə hɪz hænz, bɪɡ ɪnʌf tə kʌvɝ ə hjumən hɛd - "bʌɾ aɪ stɪl θɪŋk - "

Loial's ears twitched, and his head turned toward Rand. When he saw who it was, the Ogier's face split in a grin, and he came over. "Ah, there you are." His voice was a deep bumblebee rumble. "I did not see you at the Welcome. That was something I had not seen before. Two things. The Shienaran Welcome, and the Amyrlin Seat. She looks tired, don't you think? It cannot be easy, being Amyrlin. Worse than being an Elder, I suppose." He paused, with a thoughtful look, but only for a breath. "Tell me, Rand, do you play at dice, too? They play a simpler game here, with only three dice. We use four in the stedding. They won't let me play, you know. They just say, 'Glory to the Builders,' and will not bet against me. I don't think that's fair, do you? The dice they use are rather small" - he frowned at one of his hands, big enough to cover a human head - "but I still think - "

ɹænd ɡɹæbd ɪz ɑɹm ən kʌɾ ɪm ɔf. ðə bɪldɝz! "lɔɪəl, oʊɡiɝ bɪl fæl dæɹə, dɪdn ðeɪ? dʒju noʊ ɛni weɪ aʊɾ ɪksɛp baɪ ðə ɡeɪts? ə kɹɔl hoʊl. ə dʒɹeɪn paɪp. ɛniθɪŋ əɾ ɔl, ɪf ɪts bɪɡ ɪnʌf fəɹ ə mæn tə wɪɡəl θɹu. aʊɾ ə ðə wɪnd wəd bi ɡʊd, tu."

Rand grabbed his arm and cut him off. The Builders! "Loial, Ogier built Fal Dara, didn't they? Do you know any way out except by the gates? A crawl hole. A drain pipe. Anything at all, if it's big enough for a man to wiggle through. Out of the wind would be good, too."

lɔɪəl ɡeɪv ə peɪnd ɡɹɪmɑs, ði ɛnz ə hɪz aɪbɹaʊz ɔlmoʊs bɹʌʃɪŋ ɪz tʃiks. "ɹænd, oʊɡiɝ bɪl mæfəl dɑɾɝɑnɛl, bʌt ðət sɪɾi wɑz dɪstʃɹɔɪɾ ɪn ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz. ðɪs" - hi tʌtʃt ðə stoʊn wɔl laɪtli wɪð bɹɔd fɪŋɡɝtɪps - "wɑz bɪl baɪ mɛn. aɪ kən skɛtʃ ə plæn ə mæfəl dɑɾɝɑnɛl - aɪ sɔ ðə mæps, wʌns, ɪn ən oʊl bʊk ɪn stɛɾɪŋ ʃæŋktaɪ - bʌɾ ə fæl dæɹə, aɪ noʊ noʊ mɔɹ ðən ju. ɪts wɛl bɪlt, ðoʊ, ɪzən ɪt? stɑɹk, bʌt wɛl meɪd."

Loial gave a pained grimace, the ends of his eyebrows almost brushing his cheeks. "Rand, Ogier built Mafal Dadaranell, but that city was destroyed in the Trolloc Wars. This" - he touched the stone wall lightly with broad fingertips - "was built by men. I can sketch a plan of Mafal Dadaranell - I saw the maps, once, in an old book in Stedding Shangtai - but of Fal Dara, I know no more than you. It is well built, though, isn't it? Stark, but well made."

ɹænd slʌmpt əɡɛns ðə wɔl, skwizɪŋ ɪz aɪz ʃʌt. "aɪ niɾ ə weɪ aʊt," hi wɪspɝd. "ðə ɡeɪts ɑɹ bɑɹd, ən ðeɪ woʊn lɛɾ ɛniwʌn pæs, bʌɾ aɪ niɾ ə weɪ aʊt."

Rand slumped against the wall, squeezing his eyes shut. "I need a way out," he whispered. "The gates are barred, and they won't let anyone pass, but I need a way out."

"bʌt waɪ, ɹænd?" lɔɪəl sɛd sloʊli. "noʊ wʌn hɪɹ wɪl hɝt ju. ɑɹ jə ɔl ɹaɪt? ɹænd?" sʌɾənli hɪz vɔɪs ɹoʊz. "mæt! pɛɹɪn! aɪ θɪŋk ɹænd ɪz sɪk."

"But why, Rand?" Loial said slowly. "No one here will hurt you. Are you all right? Rand?" Suddenly his voice rose. "Mat! Perrin! I think Rand is sick."

ɹænd oʊpən ɪz aɪz tə si hɪz fɹɛnz stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ ʌp aʊɾ ə ðə nɑɾ ə dɪsɝz. mæt kɔθən, lɔŋ-lɪmd əz ə stɔɹk, wɛɹɪŋ ə hæf smaɪl əz ɪf i sɔ sʌmθɪŋ fʌni ðət noʊ wʌn ɛls sɔ. ʃæɡi-hɛɹd pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə, wɪð hɛvi ʃoʊldɝz ən θɪk ɑɹmz fɹəm ɪz wɝk əz ə blæksmɪθs əpɹɛntəs. ðeɪ boʊθ stɪl wɔɹ ðɛɹ tu ɹɪvɝz ɡɑɹb, pleɪn ən stɝɾi, bʌt tʃɹævəl-wɔɹn.

Rand opened his eyes to see his friends straightening up out of the knot of dicers. Mat Cauthon, long-limbed as a stork, wearing a half smile as if he saw something funny that no one else saw. Shaggy-haired Perrin Aybara, with heavy shoulders and thick arms from his work as a blacksmith's apprentice. They both still wore their Two Rivers garb, plain and sturdy, but travel-worn.

mæt tɔs ðə daɪs bæk ɪndə ðə sɛmɪsɝkəl əz i stɛpt aʊt, ən wʌn ə ðə mɛn kɔld, "hɪɹ, saʊθlændɝ, jə kæn kwɪt waɪl jəɹ wɪnɪŋ."

Mat tossed the dice back into the semicircle as he stepped out, and one of the men called, "Here, southlander, you can't quit while you're winning."

"bɛɾɝ ðən wən aɪm luzɪŋ," mæt sɛd wɪð ə læf. ʌnkɑnʃəsli hi tʌtʃt ɪz koʊɾ ət ðə weɪst, ən ɹænd wɪnst. mæt hæɾ ə dæɡɝ wɪð ə ɹubi ɪn ɪts hɪlt ʌndɝ ðɛɹ, ə dæɡɝ i wɑz nɛvɝ wɪθaʊt, ə dæɡɝ i kəd nɑt bi wɪθaʊt. ɪt wɑz ə teɪntɪd bleɪd, fɹəm ðə dɛd sɪɾi ʌv ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ, teɪntɪɾ ən twɪstəd baɪ ən ivəl ɔlmoʊst əz bæɾ əz ðə dɑɹk wʌn, ði ivəl ðət hæd kɪld ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ tu θaʊzən jɪɹz bɪfɔɹ, jɛt stɪl lɪvd əmʌŋ ði əbændən ɹuənz. ðət teɪnt wəd kɪl mæt ɪf i kɛp ðə dæɡɝ; ɪt wəd kɪl ɪm ivən fæstɝ ɪf i pʊɾ ɪɾ əsaɪd. "jul əv ənʌðɝ tʃæns tə wɪn ɪt bæk." ɹaɪ snɔɹts fɹəm ðə nilɪŋ mɛn ɪndəkeɪɾəd ðeɪ dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ðəɹ wɑz mʌtʃ tʃæns ə ðæt.

"Better than when I'm losing," Mat said with a laugh. Unconsciously he touched his coat at the waist, and Rand winced. Mat had a dagger with a ruby in its hilt under there, a dagger he was never without, a dagger he could not be without. It was a tainted blade, from the dead city of Shadar Logoth, tainted and twisted by an evil almost as bad as the Dark One, the evil that had killed Shadar Logoth two thousand years before, yet still lived among the abandoned ruins. That taint would kill Mat if he kept the dagger; it would kill him even faster if he put it aside. "You'll have another chance to win it back." Wry snorts from the kneeling men indicated they did not think there was much chance of that.

pɛɹɪn kɛpt ɪz aɪz daʊn əz i fɑloʊd mæt əkɹɔs tə ɹænd. pɛɹɪn ɔlweɪz kɛpt ɪz aɪz daʊn ðiz deɪz, ən ɪz ʃoʊldɝz sæɡd əz ɪf i kæɹiɾ ə weɪt tu hɛvi ivən fəɹ ðɛɹ wɪdθ.

Perrin kept his eyes down as he followed Mat across to Rand. Perrin always kept his eyes down these days, and his shoulders sagged as if he carried a weight too heavy even for their width.

"wʌts ðə mæɾɝ, ɹænd?" mæt æskt. "jɔɹ əz waɪɾ əz jəɹ ʃɝt. heɪ! wɛɹ dɪd jə ɡɛt ðoʊz kloʊðz? jə tɝnɪŋ ʃaɪnɝən? meɪbi əl baɪ maɪsɛlf ə koʊt laɪk ðæt, ən ə faɪn ʃɝt." hi ʃʊk ɪz koʊt pɑkət, pɹədusɪŋ ə klɪŋk ə kɔɪnz. "aɪ sim tə hæv lʌk wɪð ðə daɪs. aɪ kən hɑɹdli tʌtʃ əm wɪθaʊt wɪnɪŋ."

"What's the matter, Rand?" Mat asked. "You're as white as your shirt. Hey! Where did you get those clothes? You turning Shienaran? Maybe I'll buy myself a coat like that, and a fine shirt." He shook his coat pocket, producing a clink of coins. "I seem to have luck with the dice. I can hardly touch them without winning."

"ju doʊn əv tə baɪ ɛniθɪŋ," ɹænd sɛd taɪɹədli. "mɔɪɹeɪn hæɾ ɔl əɹ kloʊðz ɹipleɪst. ðəɹ bɝn ɔlɹɛɾi fəɹ ɔl aɪ noʊ, ɔl bʌt wʌt jə tu ɑɹ wɛɹɪŋ. ilænsu wɪl pɹɑbli bi ɝaʊn tə kəlɛk ðoʊz, tu, soʊ aɪd tʃeɪnʒ fæst ɪf aɪ wɝ ju, bɪfɔɹ ʃi teɪks əm ɔf jəɹ bæk." pɛɹɪn stɪl dɪd nɑt lʊk ʌp, bʌɾ ɪz tʃiks tɝn ɹɛd; mæts ɡɹɪn dipənd, ðoʊ ɪt lʊk fɔɹst. ðeɪ tu hæd hæɾ ɪnkaʊntɝz ɪn ðə bæθs, ən oʊnli mæt tʃɹaɪd tə pɹitɛn ɪt dɪd nɑt mæɾɝ. "æn aɪm nɑt sɪk. aɪ dʒʌs nid tə ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə hɪɹ. ði æmɪɝlɪn siɾ ɪz hɪɹ. læn sɛd . . . hi sɛd wɪð əɹ hɪɹ, ɪt wʊɾə bɪn bɛɾɝ fəɹ mi ɪf aɪ wɝ ɡɔn ə wik. aɪ nid tə liv, ən ɔl ðə ɡeɪts ɑɹ bɑɹd."

"You don't have to buy anything," Rand said tiredly. "Moiraine had all our clothes replaced. They're burned already for all I know, all but what you two are wearing. Elansu will probably be around to collect those, too, so I'd change fast if I were you, before she takes them off your back." Perrin still did not look up, but his cheeks turned red; Mat's grin deepened, though it looked forced. They too had had encounters in the baths, and only Mat tried to pretend it did not matter. "And I'm not sick. I just need to get out of here. The Amyrlin Seat is here. Lan said . . . he said with her here, it would have been better for me if I were gone a week. I need to leave, and all the gates are barred."

"hi sɛd ðæt?" mæt fɹaʊnd. "aɪ doʊn ʌndɝstænd. hid nɛvɝ seɪ ɛniθɪŋ əɡɛnst ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. waɪ naʊ? lʊk, ɹænd, aɪ doʊn laɪk ɛɛs sədaɪ ɛni mɔɹ ðən jə du, bʌt ðeɪ ɑɹən gɑnə də ɛniθɪŋ tə ʌs." hi loʊɝɾ ɪz vɔɪs tə seɪ ðæt, ən lʊkt oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ tə si ɪf ɛni ʌv ðə ɡæmblɝz wɑz lɪsnɪŋ. fɪɹd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ maɪt bi, bʌɾ ɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz, ðeɪ wɝ fɑɹ fɹəm biɪŋ heɪɾəd, ən ə dɪsɹɪspɛkfəl kɑmɛn əbaʊɾ əm kəd læn jə ɪn ə faɪt, əɹ wɝs. "lʊk ət mɔɪɹeɪn. ʃi ɪzən soʊ bæd, ivən ɪf ʃiz ɛɛs sədaɪ. jəɹ θɪŋkɪŋ laɪk oʊl sɛn bui tɛlɪŋ ɪz tɔl teɪlz bæk hoʊm, ɪn ðə waɪnspɹɪŋ ɪn. aɪ min, ʃi hæzən hɝɾ ʌs, ən ðeɪ woʊnt. waɪ wəd ðeɪ?"

"He said that?" Mat frowned. "I don't understand. He'd never say anything against an Aes Sedai. Why now? Look, Rand, I don't like Aes Sedai any more than you do, but they aren't going to do anything to us." He lowered his voice to say that, and looked over his shoulder to see if any of the gamblers was listening. Feared the Aes Sedai might be, but in the Borderlands, they were far from being hated, and a disrespectful comment about them could land you in a fight, or worse. "Look at Moiraine. She isn't so bad, even if she is Aes Sedai. You're thinking like old Cenn Buie telling his tall tales back home, in the Winespring Inn. I mean, she hasn't hurt us, and they won't. Why would they?"

pɛɹɪnz aɪz lɪftəd. jɛloʊ aɪz, ɡlimɪŋ ɪn ðə dɪm laɪt laɪk bɝnɪʃt ɡoʊld. mɔɪɹeɪn hæzən hɝɾ ʌs? ɹænd θɔt. pɛɹɪnz aɪz hæd bɪn əz dip ə bɹaʊn əz mæts wən ðeɪ lɛf ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. ɹænd hæd noʊ aɪdiə haʊ ðə tʃeɪnʒ hæd kʌm əbaʊt - pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt wɑnə tɔk əbaʊɾ ɪt, əɹ əbaʊt vɛɹi mʌtʃ ʌv ɛniθɪŋ sɪns ɪt hæpənd - bʌɾ ɪt hæd kʌm ət ðə seɪm taɪm əz ðə slʌmp ɪn ɪz ʃoʊldɝz, ən ə dɪstəns ɪn ɪz mænɝ əz ɪf i fɛlt əloʊn ivən wɪð fɹɛnz ɝaʊn hɪm. pɛɹɪnz aɪz ən mæts dæɡɝ. niðɝ wʊɾə hæpən ɪf ðeɪ hæd nɑt lɛft ɛmənz fild, ən ɪt wɑz mɔɪɹeɪn u hæd teɪkən əm əweɪ. hi nu ðət wɑz nɑt fɛɹ. ðeɪ wəd pɹɑbli ɔl bi dɛɾ ət tʃɹɑləks' hænz, ən ə ɡʊd pɑɹɾ ʌv ɛmənz fild əz wɛl, ɪf ʃi hæd nɑt kʌm tə ðɛɹ vɪlədʒ. bʌt ðət dɪd nɑt meɪk pɛɹɪn læf ðə weɪ hi juz tə, əɹ teɪk ðə dæɡɝ fɹəm mæts bɛlt. ən mi? ɪf aɪ wɑz hoʊm ən stɪl əlaɪv, wəɾ aɪ stɪl bi wʌɾ aɪm naʊ? ət list aɪ wʊdn bi wɝiɪŋ əbaʊt wʌt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑɹ gɑnə də tə mi.

Perrin's eyes lifted. Yellow eyes, gleaming in the dim light like burnished gold. Moiraine hasn't hurt us? Rand thought. Perrin's eyes had been as deep a brown as Mat's when they left the Two Rivers. Rand had no idea how the change had come about - Perrin did not want to talk about it, or about very much of anything since it happened - but it had come at the same time as the slump in his shoulders, and a distance in his manner as if he felt alone even with friends around him. Perrin's eyes and Mat's dagger. Neither would have happened if they had not left Emond's Field, and it was Moiraine who had taken them away. He knew that was not fair. They would probably all be dead at Trollocs' hands, and a good part of Emond's Field as well, if she had not come to their village. But that did not make Perrin laugh the way he used to, or take the dagger from Mat's belt. And me? If I was home and still alive, would I still be what I am now? At least I wouldn't be worrying about what the Aes Sedai are going to do to me.

mæt wɑz stɪl lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪm kwɪtsɪkli, ən pɛɹɪn hæd ɹeɪzd ɪz hɛɾ ɪnʌf tə stɛɹ fɹəm ʌndɝ ɪz aɪbɹaʊz. lɔɪəl weɪɾəd peɪʃənli. ɹænd kəd nɑt tɛl əm waɪ hi hæd tə steɪ əweɪ fɹəm ði æmɪɝlɪn sit. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌɾ i wɑz. læn nu, ən mɔɪɹeɪn. ən ɛɡwin, ən nɪneɪiv. hi wɪʃt nʌn ə ðɛm nu, ən moʊst ʌv ɔl i wɪʃt ɛɡwin dɪd nɑt, bʌɾ ət lis mæt ən pɛɹɪn - ən lɔɪəl, tu - bɪlivd i wɑz stɪl ðə seɪm. hi θɔɾ i wəd ɹæðɝ daɪ ðən lɛɾ əm noʊ, ðən si ðə hɛzəteɪʃən ən wɝi hi səmtaɪmz kɑɾ ɪn ɛɡwinz aɪz, ən nɪneɪivz, ivən wən ðeɪ wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ ðɛɹ bɛst.

Mat was still looking at him quizzically, and Perrin had raised his head enough to stare from under his eyebrows. Loial waited patiently. Rand could not tell them why he had to stay away from the Amyrlin Seat. They did not know what he was. Lan knew, and Moiraine. And Egwene, and Nynaeve. He wished none of them knew, and most of all he wished Egwene did not, but at least Mat and Perrin - and Loial, too - believed he was still the same. He thought he would rather die than let them know, than see the hesitation and worry he sometimes caught in Egwene's eyes, and Nynaeve's, even when they were trying their best.

"sʌmbɑɾiz . . . wɑtʃɪŋ mi," hi sɛd faɪnəli. "fɑloʊɪŋ mi. oʊnli. . . . oʊnli, ðɛɹz noʊbɑdi ðɛɹ."

"Somebody's . . . watching me," he said finally. "Following me. Only. . . . Only, there's nobody there."

pɛɹɪnz hɛd dʒɝkt ʌp, ən mæt lɪkt ɪz lɪps ən wɪspɝd, "eɪ feɪd?"

Perrin's head jerked up, and Mat licked his lips and whispered, "A Fade?"

"ʌv kɔɹs nɑt," lɔɪəl snɔɹɾɪd. "haʊ kəd wʌn ə ði aɪləs ɛntɝ fæl dæɹə, taʊn əɹ kip? baɪ lɔ, noʊ wʌn meɪ haɪɾ ɪz feɪs ɪnsaɪd ðə taʊn wɔlz, ən ðə læmplaɪɾɝz ɑɹ tʃɑɹdʒd wɪð kipɪŋ ðə stʃɹits lɪɾ ət naɪt soʊ ðəɹ ɪzən ə ʃædoʊ fəɹ ə mɹdʒɹɑl tə haɪɾ ɪn. ɪt kəd nɑt hæpən."

"Of course not," Loial snorted. "How could one of the Eyeless enter Fal Dara, town or keep? By law, no one may hide his face inside the town walls, and the lamplighters are charged with keeping the streets lit at night so there isn't a shadow for a Myrddraal to hide in. It could not happen."

"wɔlz doʊn stɑp ə feɪd," mæt mʌɾɝd. "nɑt wən ɪt wɑns tə kʌm ɪn. aɪ doʊnt noʊ əz lɔz ən læmps wɪl də ɛni bɛɾɝ." hi dɪd nɑt saʊn laɪk sʌmwʌn u hæd hæf θɔt feɪdz wɝ oʊnli ɡlimənz teɪlz lɛs ðən hæf ə jɪɹ bɪfɔɹ. hi hæd sin tu mʌtʃ, tu.

"Walls don't stop a Fade," Mat muttered. "Not when it wants to come in. I don't know as laws and lamps will do any better." He did not sound like someone who had half thought Fades were only gleemen's tales less than half a year before. He had seen too much, too.

"æn ðəɹ wɑz ðə wɪnd," ɹænd æɾəd. hɪz vɔɪs hɑɹdli ʃʊk əz i toʊld wʌt hæd hæpən ɑn ðə taʊɝ tɑp. pɛɹɪnz fɪsts taɪɾənd əntɪl ɪz nʌkəlz kɹækt. "aɪ dʒʌst wɑnə liv hɪɹ," ɹænd fɪnɪʃt. "aɪ wɑnə ɡoʊ saʊθ. sʌmwɛɹ əweɪ. dʒʌst sʌmwɛɹ əweɪ."

"And there was the wind," Rand added. His voice hardly shook as he told what had happened on the tower top. Perrin's fists tightened until his knuckles cracked. "I just want to leave here," Rand finished. "I want to go south. Somewhere away. Just somewhere away."

"bʌɾ ɪf ðə ɡeɪts ɑɹ bɑɹd," mæt sɛd, "haʊ də wi ɡɛɾ aʊt?"

"But if the gates are barred," Mat said, "how do we get out?"

ɹænd stɛɹɾ ət hɪm. "wi?" hi hæd tə ɡoʊ əloʊn. ɪt wəd bi deɪnʒɝəs fəɹ ɛniwʌn nɪɹ hɪm, ɪvɛntʃəwəli. hi wəd bi deɪnʒɝəs, ən ivən mɔɪɹeɪn kəd nɑt tɛl ɪm haʊ lɔŋ i hæd. "mæt, jə noʊ juv tə ɡoʊ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn wɪð mɔɪɹeɪn. ʃi sɛd ðæts ði oʊnli pleɪs jə kən bi sɛpɝeɪɾəd fɹəm ðət blʌɾi dæɡɝ wɪθaʊt daɪɪŋ. ən jə noʊ wʌt wɪl hæpən ɪf jə kip ɪt."

Rand stared at him. "We?" He had to go alone. It would be dangerous for anyone near him, eventually. He would be dangerous, and even Moiraine could not tell him how long he had. "Mat, you know you have to go to Tar Valon with Moiraine. She said that's the only place you can be separated from that bloody dagger without dying. And you know what will happen if you keep it."

mæt tʌtʃt ɪz koʊɾ oʊvɝ ðə dæɡɝ, nɑt simɪŋ tə ɹilaɪz wʌɾ i wɑz duɪŋ. " 'æn ɛɛs sədaɪz ɡɪft ɪz beɪt fəɹ ə fɪʃ,' " hi kwoʊɾəd. "wɛl, meɪbi aɪ doʊnt wɑnə pʊt ðə hʊk ɪn maɪ maʊθ. meɪbi wʌtɛvɝ ʃi wɑns tə də ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn ɪz wɝs ðən ɪf aɪ doʊnt ɡoʊ əɾ ɔl. meɪbi ʃiz laɪɪŋ. 'ðə tʃɹuθ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ tɛlz ɪz nɛvɝ ðə tʃɹuθ jə θɪŋk ɪɾ ɪz.' "

Mat touched his coat over the dagger, not seeming to realize what he was doing. " 'An Aes Sedai's gift is bait for a fish,' " he quoted. "Well, maybe I don't want to put the hook in my mouth. Maybe whatever she wants to do in Tar Valon is worse than if I don't go at all. Maybe she's lying. 'The truth an Aes Sedai tells is never the truth you think it is.' "

"ju hæv ɛni mɔɹ oʊl seɪɪŋz jə wɑnə ɹɪd jɝsɛlf ʌv?" ɹænd æskt. " 'ə saʊθ wɪn bɹɪŋz ə wɔɹm ɡɛst, ə nɔɹθ waɪn ən ɛmpti haʊs'? 'ə pɪɡ peɪntəd ɡoʊld ɪz stɪl ə pɪɡ'? wʌɾ əbaʊt, 'tɔk ʃiɹz noʊ ʃip'? 'ə fulz wɝdz ɑɹ dʌst'?"

"You have any more old sayings you want to rid yourself of?" Rand asked. " 'A south wind brings a warm guest, a north wind an empty house'? 'A pig painted gold is still a pig'? What about, 'talk shears no sheep'? 'A fool's words are dust'?"

"izi, ɹænd," pɛɹɪn sɛd sɔfli. "ðɛɹ ɪz noʊ nid tə bi soʊ ɹʌf."

"Easy, Rand," Perrin said softly. "There is no need to be so rough."

"ɪzən ðɛɹ? meɪbi aɪ doʊnt wɑn jə tu ɡoʊɪŋ wɪð mi, ɔlweɪz hæŋɪŋ ɝaʊnd, fɔlɪŋ ɪndə tʃɹʌbəl ən ɪkspɛktɪŋ mi tə pʊl jə aʊt. jə ɛvɝ θɪŋk ə ðæt? bɝn mi, dɪɾ ɪɾ ɛvɝ əkɝ tə jə aɪ maɪt bi taɪɝɾ ʌv ɔlweɪz hævɪŋ jə ðəɹ wɛnɛvɝ aɪ tɝn ɝaʊnd? ɔlweɪz ðɛɹ, ən aɪm taɪɝɾ ʌv ɪt." ðə hɝɾ ɑn pɛɹɪnz feɪs kʌɾ ɪm laɪk ə naɪf, bʌɾ i pʊʃt ɑn ɹɪlɛnləsli. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ səm hɪɹ θɪŋk ɪm ə lɔɹd. ə lɔɹd. meɪbi aɪ laɪk ðæt. bʌt lʊk ət ju, dɪsɪŋ wɪð steɪbəlɪhənz. wən aɪ ɡoʊ, aɪ ɡoʊ baɪ maɪsɛlf. jə tu kən ɡoʊ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn əɹ ɡoʊ hæŋ jʊɹsɛlvz, bʌɾ aɪ liv hɪɹ əloʊn."

"Isn't there? Maybe I don't want you two going with me, always hanging around, falling into trouble and expecting me to pull you out. You ever think of that? Burn me, did it ever occur to you I might be tired of always having you there whenever I turn around? Always there, and I'm tired of it." The hurt on Perrin's face cut him like a knife, but he pushed on relentlessly. "There are some here think I'm a lord. A lord. Maybe I like that. But look at you, dicing with stablehands. When I go, I go by myself. You two can go to Tar Valon or go hang yourselves, but I leave here alone."

mæts feɪs hæd ɡɔn stɪf, ən i klʌtʃt ðə dæɡɝ θɹu hɪz koʊt tɪl ɪz nʌkəlz wɝ waɪt. "ɪf ðəɾ ɪz haʊ jə wɑn ɪt," hi sɛd koʊldli. "aɪ θɔt wi wɝ. . . . haʊɛvɝ jə wɑn ɪt, ælθɹ. bʌɾ ɪf aɪ dɪsaɪd tə liv ət ðə seɪm taɪm jə du, əl ɡoʊ, ən jə kən stæn klɪɹ ə mi."

Mat's face had gone stiff, and he clutched the dagger through his coat till his knuckles were white. "If that is how you want it," he said coldly. "I thought we were. . . . However you want it, al'Thor. But if I decide to leave at the same time you do, I'll go, and you can stand clear of me."

"noʊbɑdi ɪz ɡoʊɪŋ ɛniwɛɹ," pɛɹɪn sɛd, "ɪf ðə ɡeɪts ɑɹ bɑɹd." hi wɑz stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə flɔɹ əɡɛn. læftɝ ɹoʊl fɹəm ðə ɡæmblɝz əɡɛns ðə wɔl əz sʌmwʌn lɔst.

"Nobody is going anywhere," Perrin said, "if the gates are barred." He was staring at the floor again. Laughter rolled from the gamblers against the wall as someone lost.

"ɡoʊ əɹ steɪ," lɔɪəl sɛd, "təɡɛðɝ əɹ əpɑɹt, ɪt dʌzn mæɾɝ. jə ɑɹ ɔl θɹi tɑvɝən. ivən aɪ kən si ɪt, ən aɪ doʊn əv ðət tælənt, dʒʌs baɪ wʌt hæpənz ɝaʊn ju. ən mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ sɛz ɪt, tu."

"Go or stay," Loial said, "together or apart, it doesn't matter. You are all three ta'veren. Even I can see it, and I don't have that Talent, just by what happens around you. And Moiraine Sedai says it, too."

mæt θɹu ʌp ɪz hænz. "noʊ mɔɹ, lɔɪəl. aɪ doʊnt wɑnə hɪɹ əbaʊt ðəɾ ɛnimɔɹ."

Mat threw up his hands. "No more, Loial. I don't want to hear about that anymore."

lɔɪəl ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "wɛðɝ jə hɪɹ ɪɾ əɹ nɑt, ɪts stɪl tʃɹu. ðə wil ə taɪm wivz ðə pæɾɝn ə ði eɪdʒ, juzɪŋ ðə laɪvz ə mɛn fəɹ θɹɛd. ən jə θɹi ɑɹ tɑvɝən, sɛntɝpɔɪns ə ðə wivɪŋ."

Loial shook his head. "Whether you hear it or not, it is still true. The Wheel of Time weaves the Pattern of the Age, using the lives of men for thread. And you three are ta'veren, centerpoints of the weaving."

"noʊ mɔɹ, lɔɪəl."

"No more, Loial."

"fɔɹ ə taɪm, ðə wil wɪl bɛn ðə pæɾɝn ɝaʊn jə θɹi, wʌtɛvɝ jə du. ən wʌtɛvɝ jə də ɪz mɔɹ laɪkli tə bi tʃoʊzən baɪ ðə wil ðən baɪ ju. tɑvɝən pʊl hɪstɝi əlɔŋ bɪhaɪn əm ən ʃeɪp ðə pæɾɝn dʒʌs baɪ biɪŋ, bʌt ðə wil wivz tɑvɝən ɑn ə taɪɾɝ laɪn ðən ʌðɝ mɛn. wɛɹɛvɝ jə ɡoʊ ən wʌtɛvɝ jə du, əntɪl ðə wil tʃuzəz ʌðɝwaɪz jəl - "

"For a time, the Wheel will bend the Pattern around you three, whatever you do. And whatever you do is more likely to be chosen by the Wheel than by you. Ta'veren pull history along behind them and shape the Pattern just by being, but the Wheel weaves ta'veren on a tighter line than other men. Wherever you go and whatever you do, until the Wheel chooses otherwise you will - "

"noʊ mɔɹ!" mæt ʃaʊɾəd. ðə mɛn dɪsɪŋ lʊkt ɝaʊnd, ən i ɡlɛɹɾ əɾ əm əntɪl ðeɪ bɛn bæk tə ðɛɹ ɡeɪm.

"No more!" Mat shouted. The men dicing looked around, and he glared at them until they bent back to their game.

"aɪ æm sɑɹi, mæt," lɔɪəl ɹʌmbəld. "aɪ noʊ aɪ tɔk tu mʌtʃ, bʌɾ aɪ dɪd nɑt min - "

"I am sorry, Mat," Loial rumbled. "I know I talk too much, but I did not mean - "

"aɪ æm nɑt steɪɪŋ hɪɹ," mæt toʊl ðə ɹæftɝz, "wɪð ə bɪɡməðd oʊɡiɝ ən ə ful huz hɛɾ ɪz tu bɪɡ fəɹ ə hæt. jə kʌmɪŋ, pɛɹɪn?" pɛɹɪn saɪd, ən ɡlænst ət ɹænd, ðən nɑɾəd.

"I am not staying here," Mat told the rafters, "with a bigmouthed Ogier and a fool whose head is too big for a hat. You coming, Perrin?" Perrin sighed, and glanced at Rand, then nodded.

ɹænd wɑtʃt əm ɡoʊ wɪð ə stɪk kɑɾ ɪn ɪz θɹɛt. aɪ mʌst ɡoʊ əloʊn. laɪt hɛlp mi, aɪ hæv tə.

Rand watched them go with a stick caught in his threat. I must go alone. Light help me, I have to.

lɔɪəl wɑz stɛɹɪŋ æftɝ ðɛm, tu, aɪbɹaʊz dʒɹupɪŋ wɝidli. "ɹænd, aɪ ɹɪli dɪdn min tə - "

Loial was staring after them, too, eyebrows drooping worriedly. "Rand, I really didn't mean to - "

ɹænd meɪɾ ɪz vɔɪs hɑɹʃ. "wʌɾ ɑɹ jə weɪɾɪŋ fɔɹ? ɡoʊ ɑn wɪð ðɛm! aɪ doʊn si waɪ jəɹ stɪl hɪɹ. jə ɑɹ noʊ jus tə mi ɪf jə doʊnt noʊ ə weɪ aʊt. ɡoʊ ɑn! ɡoʊ faɪn jəɹ tʃɹiz, ən jəɹ pɹɛʃəs ɡɹoʊvz, ɪf ðeɪ hævən ɔl bɪn kʌt daʊn, ən ɡʊd ɹɪɾəns tə ðɛm ɪf ðeɪ hæv."

Rand made his voice harsh. "What are you waiting for? Go on with them! I don't see why you're still here. You are no use to me if you don't know a way out. Go on! Go find your trees, and your precious groves, if they haven't all been cut down, and good riddance to them if they have."

lɔɪəlz aɪz, əz bɪɡ əz kʌps, lʊk sɝpɹaɪzd ən hɝt, ət fɝst, bʌt sloʊli ðeɪ taɪɾənd ɪndə wʌɾ ɔlmoʊs maɪt bi æŋɡɝ. ɹænd dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ɪt kəd bi. səm ə ði oʊl stɔɹiz kleɪmd oʊɡiɝ wɝ fɪɹs, ðoʊ ðeɪ nɛvɝ sɛd haʊ, ɪɡzækli, bʌt ɹænd hæd nɛvɝ mɛɾ ɛniwʌn əz dʒɛntəl əz lɔɪəl.

Loial's eyes, as big as cups, looked surprised and hurt, at first, but slowly they tightened into what almost might be anger. Rand did not think it could be. Some of the old stories claimed Ogier were fierce, though they never said how, exactly, but Rand had never met anyone as gentle as Loial.

"ɪf jə wɪʃ ɪt soʊ, ɹænd ælθɹ," lɔɪəl sɛd stɪfli. hi ɡeɪv ə ɹɪdʒəd baʊ ən stɔkt əweɪ æftɝ mæt ən pɛɹɪn.

"If you wish it so, Rand al'Thor," Loial said stiffly. He gave a rigid bow and stalked away after Mat and Perrin.

ɹænd slʌmpt əɡɛns ðə stæk sæks ʌv ɡɹeɪn. wɛl, ə vɔɪs ɪn ɪz hɛd tɔntɪd, jə dɪɾ ɪt, dɪdn ju. aɪ hæd tə, hi toʊld ɪt. əl bi deɪnʒɝəs dʒʌs tə bi ɝaʊnd. blʌɾ ən æʃəz, aɪm gɑnə ɡoʊ mæd, ænd. . . . noʊ! noʊ, aɪ woʊnt! əl nɑt juz ðə paʊɝ, ən ðən aɪ woʊnt ɡoʊ mæd, ænd. . . . bʌɾ aɪ kæn ɹɪsk ɪt. aɪ kænt, doʊn jə si? bʌt ðə vɔɪs oʊnli læft ət hɪm.

Rand slumped against the stacked sacks of grain. Well, a voice in his head taunted, you did it, didn't you. I had to, he told it. I will be dangerous just to be around. Blood and ashes, I'm going to go mad, and. . . . No! No, I won't! I will not use the Power, and then I won't go mad, and. . . . But I can't risk it. I can't, don't you see? But the voice only laughed at him.

ðə ɡæmblɝz wɝ lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm, hi ɹilaɪzd. ɔl ə ðɛm, stɪl nilɪŋ əɡɛns ðə wɔl, hæd tɝn tə stɛɹ ət hɪm. ʃaɪnɝənz ʌv ɛni klæs wɝ ɔlmoʊst ɔlweɪz pəlaɪɾ ən kɝɛkt, ivən tə blʌɾ ɛnəmiz, ən oʊɡiɝ wɝ nɛvɝ ɛni ɛnəmiz ə ʃaɪnɝ. ʃɑk fɪl ðə ɡæmblɝz' aɪz. ðɛɹ feɪsəz wɝ blæŋk, bʌt ðɛɹ aɪz sɛd wʌɾ i hæd dʌn wɑz ɹɔŋ. pɑɹɾ ə hɪm θɔt ðeɪ wɝ ɹaɪt, ən ðət dʒɹoʊv ðɛɹ saɪlən ækjəzeɪʃən dip. ðeɪ oʊnli lʊkt ət hɪm, bʌɾ i stʌmbəld aʊɾ ə ðə stɔɹɹum əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ tʃeɪsɪŋ hɪm.

The gamblers were looking at him, he realized. All of them, still kneeling against the wall, had turned to stare at him. Shienarans of any class were almost always polite and correct, even to blood enemies, and Ogier were never any enemies of Shienar. Shock filled the gamblers' eyes. Their faces were blank, but their eyes said what he had done was wrong. Part of him thought they were right, and that drove their silent accusation deep. They only looked at him, but he stumbled out of the storeroom as if they were chasing him.

nʌmbli hi wɛn ɑn θɹu ðə stɔɹɹumz, hʌntɪŋ ə pleɪs tə sɪkɹit hɪmsɛlf əntɪl səm tʃɹæfɪk wɑz əlaʊd θɹu ðə ɡeɪts əɡɛn. ðən i kəd haɪɾ ɪn ðə bɑɾəm ʌv ə vɪktʃueɪlɝz kɑɹt, meɪbi. ɪf ðeɪ dɪd nɑt sɝtʃ ðə kɑɹts ɑn ðə weɪ aʊt. ɪf ðeɪ dɪd nɑt sɝtʃ ðə stɔɹɹumz, sɝtʃ ðə hoʊl kip fəɹ hɪm. stʌbɝnli hi ɹəfjuz tə θɪŋk əbaʊt ðæt, stʌbɝnli kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾəd ɑn faɪndɪŋ ə seɪf pleɪs. bʌɾ ɛvɹi pleɪs i faʊnd - ə hɑloʊ ɪn ə stæk ʌv ɡɹeɪn sæks, ə nɛɹoʊ æli əlɔŋ ðə wɔl bɪhaɪn səm waɪn bæɹəlz, ən əbændən stɔɹɹum hæf fɪld wɪð ɛmpti kɹeɪts ən ʃædoʊz - hi kəɾ ɪmædʒən sɝtʃɝz faɪndɪŋ ɪm ðɛɹ. hi kəɾ ɪmædʒən ðəɾ ənsin wɑtʃɝ, huɛvɝ ɪt wɑz - əɹ wʌtɛvɝ - faɪndɪŋ ɪm ðɛɹ, tu. soʊ hi hʌntəɾ ɑn, θɝsti ən dʌsti ən wɪð kɑbwɛbz ɪn ɪz hɛɹ.

Numbly he went on through the storerooms, hunting a place to secrete himself until some traffic was allowed through the gates again. Then he could hide in the bottom of a victualer's cart, maybe. If they did not search the carts on the way out. If they did not search the storerooms, search the whole keep for him. Stubbornly he refused to think about that, stubbornly concentrated on finding a safe place. But every place he found - a hollow in a stack of grain sacks, a narrow alley along the wall behind some wine barrels, an abandoned storeroom half filled with empty crates and shadows - he could imagine searchers finding him there. He could imagine that unseen watcher, whoever it was - or whatever - finding him there, too. So he hunted on, thirsty and dusty and with cobwebs in his hair.

ən ðən i keɪm aʊɾ ɪndə ə dɪmli tɔɹtʃ-lɪt kɔɹəɾɝ, ən ɛɡwin wɑz kɹipɪŋ əlɔŋ ɪt, pɔzɪŋ tə pɪɹ ɪndə ðə stɔɹɹumz ʃi pæst. hɝ dɑɹk hɛɹ, hæŋɪŋ tə hɝ weɪst, wɑz kɑt bæk wɪð ə ɹɛd ɹɪbən, ən ʃi wɔɹ ə ɡus-ɡɹeɪ dʒɹɛs ɪn ðə ʃaɪnɝən fæʃən, tʃɹɪmd ɪn ɹɛd. ət ðə saɪɾ ə hɝ, sædnəs ən lɔs ɹoʊld oʊvɝ hɪm, wɝs ðən wən i hæd tʃeɪs mæt ən pɛɹɪn ən lɔɪəl əweɪ. hi hæd ɡɹoʊn ʌp θɪŋkɪŋ i wəd mɛɹi ɛɡwin wʌn deɪ; ðeɪ boʊθ hæd. bʌt naʊ. . . .

And then he came out into a dimly torch-lit corridor, and Egwene was creeping along it, pausing to peer into the storerooms she passed. Her dark hair, hanging to her waist, was caught back with a red ribbon, and she wore a goose-gray dress in the Shienaran fashion, trimmed in red. At the sight of her, sadness and loss rolled over him, worse than when he had chased Mat and Perrin and Loial away. He had grown up thinking he would marry Egwene one day; they both had. But now. . . .

ʃi dʒʌmpt wən i pɑpt aʊt ɹaɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ, ən əɹ bɹɛθ kɑt laʊdli, bʌt wʌt ʃi sɛd wɑz, "soʊ ðəɹ jə ɑɹ. mæt ən pɛɹɪn toʊl mi wʌt jə dɪd. ən lɔɪəl. aɪ noʊ wʌt jəɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə du, ɹænd, ən ɪts pleɪn fulɪʃ." ʃi kɹɔst əɹ ɑɹmz ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛsts, ən əɹ bɪɡ, dɑɹk aɪz fɪkst ɪm stɝnli. hi ɔlweɪz wʌndɝd haʊ ʃi mænədʒ tə sim tə bi lʊkɪŋ daʊn əɾ ɪm - ʃi dɪɾ ɪɾ ət wɪl - ɔlðoʊ ʃi wɑz oʊnli əz tɔl əz ɪz tʃɛst, ən tu jɪɹz jʌŋɡɝ bɪsaɪdz.

She jumped when he popped out right in front of her, and her breath caught loudly, but what she said was, "So there you are. Mat and Perrin told me what you did. And Loial. I know what you're trying to do, Rand, and it is plain foolish." She crossed her arms under her breasts, and her big, dark eyes fixed him sternly. He always wondered how she managed to seem to be looking down at him - she did it at will - although she was only as tall as his chest, and two years younger besides.

"ɡʊd," hi sɛd. hɝ hɛɹ sʌɾənli meɪɾ ɪm æŋɡɹi. hi hæd nɛvɝ sin ə ɡɹoʊn wʊmən wɪð əɹ hɛɹ ənbɹeɪɾɪd əntɪl i lɛf ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. ðɛɹ, ɛvɹi ɡɝl weɪɾəd iɡɝli fəɹ ðə wɪmənz sɝkəl ə hɝ vɪlədʒ tə seɪ ʃi wɑz oʊld ɪnʌf tə bɹeɪɾ əɹ hɛɹ. ɛɡwin sɝɾənli hæd. ən hɪɹ ʃi wɑz wɪð əɹ hɛɹ lus ɪksɛp fəɹ ə ɹɪbən. aɪ wɑnə ɡoʊ hoʊm ən kænt, ən ʃi kænt weɪt tə fɝɡɛɾ ɛmənz fild. "ju ɡoʊ əweɪ ən liv mi əloʊn, tu. jə doʊnt wɑnə kip kʌmpəni wɪð ə ʃɛpɝɾ ɛnimɔɹ. ðəɹ ɑɹ plɛnti ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ hɪɹ fəɹ jə tə mun ɝaʊnd, naʊ. ən doʊn tɛl ɛni ʌv əm jə sɔ mi. ðəɹ æftɝ mi, ən aɪ doʊnt nid jə hɛlpɪŋ ðɛm."

"Good," he said. Her hair suddenly made him angry. He had never seen a grown woman with her hair unbraided until he left the Two Rivers. There, every girl waited eagerly for the Women's Circle of her village to say she was old enough to braid her hair. Egwene certainly had. And here she was with her hair loose except for a ribbon. I want to go home and can't, and she can't wait to forget Emond's Field. "You go away and leave me alone, too. You don't want to keep company with a shepherd anymore. There are plenty of Aes Sedai here for you to moon around, now. And don't tell any of them you saw me. They're after me, and I don't need you helping them."

bɹaɪt spɑts ə kʌlɝ blumd ɪn əɹ tʃiks. "du jə θɪŋk aɪ wəd - "

Bright spots of color bloomed in her cheeks. "Do you think I would - "

hi tɝn tə wɔk əweɪ, ən wɪð ə kɹaɪ ʃi θɹu hɝsɛlf ət hɪm, flʌŋ əɹ ɑɹmz ɝaʊn ɪz lɛɡz. ðeɪ boʊθ tʌmbəl tə ðə stoʊn flɔɹ, hɪz sæɾəlbæɡz ən bʌndəlz flaɪɪŋ. hi ɡɹʌntɪd wən i hɪt, sɔɹd hɪl dɪɡɪŋ ɪndə hɪz saɪd, ən əɡɛn wən ʃi skɹæbəld ʌp ən plɑp hɝsɛlf daʊn ɑn ɪz bæk əz ɪf i wɝ ə tʃɛɹ. "maɪ mʌðɝ," ʃi sɛd fɝmli, "ɔlweɪz toʊl mi ðə bɛst weɪ tə lɝn tə dil wɪð ə mæn wɑz tə lɝn tə ɹaɪɾ ə mjul. ʃi sɛd ðeɪv əbaʊɾ ikwəl bɹeɪnz moʊst ə ðə taɪm. səmtaɪmz ðə mjul ɪz smɑɹɾɝ."

He turned to walk away, and with a cry she threw herself at him, flung her arms around his legs. They both tumbled to the stone floor, his saddlebags and bundles flying. He grunted when he hit, sword hilt digging into his side, and again when she scrabbled up and plopped herself down on his back as if he were a chair. "My mother," she said firmly, "always told me the best way to learn to deal with a man was to learn to ride a mule. She said they have about equal brains most of the time. Sometimes the mule is smarter."

hi ɹeɪzd ɪz hɛd tə lʊk oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ət hɝ. "ɡɛɾ ɔf mi, ɛɡwin. ɡɛɾ ɔf! ɛɡwin, ɪf jə doʊnt ɡɛɾ ɔf" - hi loʊɝɾ ɪz vɔɪs ɑmənəsli - "aɪl də sʌmθɪŋ tə ju. jə noʊ wʌɾ aɪ æm." hi æɾəd ə ɡlɛɹ fəɹ ɡʊd mɛʒɝ.

He raised his head to look over his shoulder at her. "Get off me, Egwene. Get off! Egwene, if you don't get off" - he lowered his voice ominously - "I'll do something to you. You know what I am." He added a glare for good measure.

ɛɡwin snɪft. "ju wʊdnt, ɪf jə kʊd. jə wəd nɑt hɝɾ ɛnibəɾi. bʌt jə kænt, ɛniweɪ. aɪ noʊ jə kænɑt tʃænəl ðə wʌn paʊɝ wɛnɛvɝ jə wɑnt; ɪt dʒʌs hæpənz, ən jə kænɑt kəntʃɹoʊl ɪt. soʊ jə ɑɹ nɑt gɑnə də ɛniθɪŋ tə mi əɹ ɛnibəɾi ɛls. aɪ, ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, hæv bɪn teɪkɪŋ lɛsənz wɪð mɔɪɹeɪn, soʊ ɪf jə doʊn lɪsən tə səm sɛns, ɹænd ælθɹ, aɪ maɪt dʒʌst sɛt jəɹ bɹitʃɪz ɑn faɪɝ. aɪ kən mænədʒ ðət mʌtʃ. jə kip ɑn əz jə ɑɹ ən si ɪf aɪ kænɑt." sʌɾənli, fəɹ dʒʌst ə moʊmənt, ðə tɔɹtʃ nɪɹəst əm ɑn ðə wɔl flɛɹɾ ʌp wɪð ə ɹɔɹ. ʃi ɡeɪv ə skwik ən stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪt, stɑɹɾəld.

Egwene sniffed. "You wouldn't, if you could. You would not hurt anybody. But you can't, anyway. I know you cannot channel the One Power whenever you want; it just happens, and you cannot control it. So you are not going to do anything to me or anybody else. I, on the other hand, have been taking lessons with Moiraine, so if you don't listen to some sense, Rand al'Thor, I might just set your breeches on fire. I can manage that much. You keep on as you are and see if I cannot." Suddenly, for just a moment, the torch nearest them on the wall flared up with a roar. She gave a squeak and stared at it, startled.

twɪstɪŋ ɝaʊnd, hi ɡɹæbd əɹ ɑɹm, pʊld əɹ ɔf ɪz bæk, ən sæɾ əɹ əɡɛns ðə wɔl. wən i sæɾ ʌp hɪmsɛlf, ʃi wɑz sɪɾɪŋ ðəɹ əkɹɔs fɹəm hɪm, ɹʌbɪŋ əɹ ɑɹm fjʊɹiəsli. "ju ɹɪli wəd hæv, wʊdn ju?" hi sɛɾ æŋɡɹəli. "jɔɹ fulɪŋ wɪð θɪŋz jə doʊn ʌndɝstænd. jə cʊɾə bɝn boʊθ ʌv əs tə tʃɑɹkoʊl!"

Twisting around, he grabbed her arm, pulled her off his back, and sat her against the wall. When he sat up himself, she was sitting there across from him, rubbing her arm furiously. "You really would have, wouldn't you?" he said angrily. "You're fooling with things you don't understand. You could have burned both of us to charcoal!"

"mɛn! wən jə kænɑt wɪn ən ɑɹɡjəmənt, jə iðɝ ɹʌn əweɪ əɹ ɹɪzɔɹt tə fɔɹs."

"Men! When you cannot win an argument, you either run away or resort to force."

"hoʊld ɑn ðɛɹ! hu tʃɹɪp hu? hu sæɾ ɑn hu? ən jə θɹɛɾənd - tʃɹaɪd! - tə - " hi ɹeɪz boʊθ hænz. "noʊ, jə doʊnt. jə də ðɪs tə mi ɔl ðə taɪm. wɛnɛvɝ jə ɹilaɪz ði ɑɹɡjəmən ɪzənt ɡoʊɪŋ ðə weɪ jə wɑnt, sʌɾənli wəɹ ɑɹɡjuɪŋ əbaʊt sʌmθɪŋ ɛls kəmplitli. nɑt ðɪs taɪm."

"Hold on there! Who tripped who? Who sat on who? And you threatened - tried! - to - " He raised both hands. "No, you don't. You do this to me all the time. Whenever you realize the argument isn't going the way you want, suddenly we are arguing about something else completely. Not this time."

"aɪ æm nɑɾ ɑɹɡjuɪŋ," ʃi sɛd kɑmli, "æn aɪm nɑt tʃeɪnʒɪŋ ðə sʌbʒɪkt, iðɝ. wʌɾ ɪz haɪɾɪŋ ɪksɛpt ɹʌnɪŋ əweɪ? ən æftɝ jə haɪd, jəl ɹʌn əweɪ fəɹ tʃɹu. ən wʌɾ əbaʊt hɝɾɪŋ mæt, ən pɛɹɪn, ən lɔɪəl? ən mi? aɪ noʊ waɪ. jəɹ əfɹeɪd jəl hɝt sʌmbɑɾi ivən wɝs ɪf jə lɛɾ əm steɪ nɪɹ ju. ɪf jə doʊn də wʌt jə ʃʊdnt, ðən jə də nɑɾ əv tə wɝi əbaʊt hɝɾɪŋ ɛnibəɾi. ɔl ðɪs ɹʌnɪŋ ɝaʊn ən stʃɹaɪkɪŋ aʊt, ən jə doʊn ivən noʊ ɪf ðɛɹz ə ɹizən. waɪ ʃəd ði æmɪɝlɪn, əɹ ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ bʌt mɔɪɹeɪn, ivən noʊ jə ɪɡzɪst?"

"I am not arguing," she said calmly, "and I am not changing the subject, either. What is hiding except running away? And after you hide, you'll run away for true. And what about hurting Mat, and Perrin, and Loial? And me? I know why. You're afraid you will hurt somebody even worse if you let them stay near you. If you don't do what you shouldn't, then you do not have to worry about hurting anybody. All this running around and striking out, and you don't even know if there's a reason. Why should the Amyrlin, or any Aes Sedai but Moiraine, even know you exist?"

fəɹ ə moʊmən i stɛɹɾ ət hɝ. ðə lɔŋɡɝ ʃi spɛnt wɪð mɔɪɹeɪn ən nɪneɪiv, ðə mɔɹ ʃi tʊk ɑn ðɛɹ mænɝ, ət list wən ʃi wɑntəd tə. ðeɪ wɝ mʌtʃ əlaɪk ət taɪmz, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ðə wɪzdəm, dɪstən ən noʊɪŋ. ɪt wɑz dɪskənsɝɾɪŋ kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ɛɡwin. faɪnəli hi toʊld əɹ wʌt læn hæd sɛd. "wʌɾ ɛls kəɾ i min?"

For a moment he stared at her. The longer she spent with Moiraine and Nynaeve, the more she took on their manner, at least when she wanted to. They were much alike at times, the Aes Sedai and the Wisdom, distant and knowing. It was disconcerting coming from Egwene. Finally he told her what Lan had said. "What else could he mean?"

hɝ hæn fɹoʊz ɑn əɹ ɑɹm, ən ʃi fɹaʊnd wɪð kɑnsəntʃɹeɪʃən. "mɔɪɹeɪn noʊz əbaʊt ju, ən ʃi hæzən dʌn ɛniθɪŋ, soʊ waɪ ʃəd ʃi naʊ? bʌɾ ɪf læn. . . ." stɪl fɹaʊnɪŋ, ʃi mɛɾ ɪz aɪz. "ðə stɔɹɹumz ɑɹ ðə fɝs pleɪs ðəl lʊk. ɪf ðeɪ də lʊk. əntɪl wi faɪn aʊɾ ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹ lʊkɪŋ, wi nid tə pʊt jə sʌmwɛɹ ðeɪ wəd nɛvɝ θɪŋk ə sɝtʃɪŋ. aɪ noʊ. ðə dʌnʒən."

Her hand froze on her arm, and she frowned with concentration. "Moiraine knows about you, and she hasn't done anything, so why should she now? But if Lan. . . ." Still frowning, she met his eyes. "The storerooms are the first place they will look. If they do look. Until we find out if they are looking, we need to put you somewhere they would never think of searching. I know. The dungeon."

hi skɹæmbəl tə hɪz fit. "ðə dʌnʒən!"

He scrambled to his feet. "The dungeon!"

"nɑɾ ɪn ə sɛl, sɪli. aɪ ɡoʊ ðəɹ səm ivnɪŋz tə vɪzət pdən feɪn. nɪneɪiv dʌz, tu. noʊ wʌn wɪl θɪŋk ɪɾ ɑɾ ɪf aɪ ɡoʊ ɝli tədeɪ. ɪn tʃɹuθ, wɪð ɛvɹibɑɾi lʊkɪŋ tə ði æmɪɝlɪn, noʊ wʌn wɪl ivən noʊɾəs ʌs."

"Not in a cell, silly. I go there some evenings to visit Padan Fain. Nynaeve does, too. No one will think it odd if I go early today. In truth, with everybody looking to the Amyrlin, no one will even notice us."

"bʌt, mɔɪɹeɪn. . . ."

"But, Moiraine. . . ."

"ʃi dʌznt ɡoʊ tə ðə dʌnʒənz tə kwɛstʃən mæstɝ feɪn. ʃiz ɪm bɹɔt tə hɝ. ən ʃiz nɑt dʌn ðət vɛɹi mʌtʃ fəɹ wiks. bɪliv mi, jəl bi seɪf ðɛɹ."

"She doesn't go to the dungeons to question Master Fain. She has him brought to her. And she has not done that very much for weeks. Believe me, you will be safe there."

stɪl, hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. pdən feɪn. "waɪ dʒju vɪzət ðə pɛdlɝ, ɛniweɪ? hiz ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd, ədmɪɾəd aʊɾ ə hɪz oʊn maʊθ, ən ə bæd wʌn. bɝn mi, ɛɡwin, hi bɹɔt ðə tʃɹɑləks tə ɛmənz fild! ðə dɑɹk wʌnz haʊnd, hi kɔl hɪmsɛlf, ən hiz bɪn snɪfɪŋ ɑn maɪ tʃɹeɪl sɪns wɪntɝnaɪt."

Still, he hesitated. Padan Fain. "Why do you visit the peddler, anyway? He's a Darkfriend, admitted out of his own mouth, and a bad one. Burn me, Egwene, he brought the Trollocs to Emond's Field! The Dark One's hound, he called himself, and he has been sniffing on my trail since Winternight."

"wɛl, hiz seɪf bɪhaɪn aɪɝn bɑɹz naʊ, ɹænd." ɪt wɑz əɹ tɝn tə hɛzəteɪt, ən ʃi lʊkt əɾ ɪm ɔlmoʊs pliɾɪŋ. "ɹænd, hiz bɹɔɾ ɪz wæɡən ɪndə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz ɛvɹi spɹɪŋ sɪns bɪfɔɹ aɪ wɑz bɔɹn. hi noʊz ɔl ðə pipəl aɪ noʊ, ɔl ðə pleɪsəz. ɪts stʃɹeɪnʒ, bʌt ðə lɔŋɡɝ hiz bɪn lɑkt ʌp, ði iziɝ ɪn hɪmsɛlf hiz bɪkʌm. ɪts ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf hiz bɹeɪkɪŋ fɹi ʌv ðə dɑɹk wʌn. hi læfs əɡɛn, ən tɛlz fʌni stɔɹiz, əbaʊɾ ɛmənz fil foʊk, ən səmtaɪmz əbaʊt pleɪsəz aɪ nɛvɝ hɝɾ ə bɪfɔɹ. səmtaɪmz hiz ɔlmoʊs laɪk ɪz oʊl sɛlf. aɪ dʒʌs laɪk tə tɔk tə sʌmbɑɾi əbaʊt hoʊm."

"Well, he is safe behind iron bars now, Rand." It was her turn to hesitate, and she looked at him almost pleading. "Rand, he has brought his wagon into the Two Rivers every spring since before I was born. He knows all the people I know, all the places. It's strange, but the longer he has been locked up, the easier in himself he has become. It's almost as if he is breaking free of the Dark One. He laughs again, and tells funny stories, about Emond's Field folk, and sometimes about places I never heard of before. Sometimes he is almost like his old self. I just like to talk to somebody about home."

sɪns aɪv bɪn əvɔɪɾɪŋ ju, hi θɔt, ən sɪns pɛɹɪnz bɪn əvɔɪɾɪŋ ɛvɹibɑɾi, ən mæts bɪn spɛndɪŋ ɔl ɪz taɪm ɡæmbəlɪŋ ən kəɹaʊzəŋ. "aɪ ʃʊdn əv kɛp tə maɪsɛlf soʊ mʌtʃ," hi mʌɾɝd, ðən saɪd. "wɛl, ɪf mɔɪɹeɪn θɪŋks ɪts seɪf ɪnʌf fəɹ ju, aɪ səpoʊz ɪts seɪf ɪnʌf fəɹ mi. bʌt ðɛɹz noʊ nid fəɹ jə tə bi mɪkst ɪn ɪt."

Since I've been avoiding you, he thought, and since Perrin's been avoiding everybody, and Mat's been spending all his time gambling and carousing. "I shouldn't have kept to myself so much," he muttered, then sighed. "Well, if Moiraine thinks it's safe enough for you, I suppose it is safe enough for me. But there's no need for you to be mixed in it."

ɛɡwin ɡɑt tə hɝ fiɾ ən kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾəd ɑn bɹʌʃɪŋ ɔf əɹ dʒɹɛs, əvɔɪɾɪŋ ɪz aɪ.

Egwene got to her feet and concentrated on brushing off her dress, avoiding his eye.

"mɔɪɹeɪn əz sɛɾ ɪts seɪf? ɛɡwin?"

"Moiraine has said it's safe? Egwene?"

"mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ hæz nɛvɝ toʊl mi aɪ kəd nɑt vɪzət mæstɝ feɪn," ʃi sɛd kɛɹfəli.

"Moiraine Sedai has never told me I could not visit Master Fain," she said carefully.

hi stɛɹɾ ət hɝ, ðən bɝst aʊt, "ju nɛvɝ æsk hɝ. ʃi dʌznt noʊ. ɛɡwin, ðæts stupəd. pdən feɪnz ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd, ən əz bæɾ əz ɛvɝ ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd wɑz."

He stared at her, then burst out, "You never asked her. She doesn't know. Egwene, that's stupid. Padan Fain's a Darkfriend, and as bad as ever a Darkfriend was."

"hi ɪz lɑkt ɪn ə keɪdʒ," ʃi sɛd stɪfli, "æn aɪ də nɑɾ əv tə æsk mɔɪɹeɪnz pɝmɪʃən fəɹ ɛvɹiθɪŋ aɪ du. ɪts ə lɪɾəl leɪt fəɹ jə tə stɑɹt wɝiɪŋ əbaʊt duɪŋ wʌɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ θɪŋks, ɪzən ɪt? naʊ, ɑɹ jə kʌmɪŋ?"

"He is locked in a cage," she said stiffly, "and I do not have to ask Moiraine's permission for everything I do. It is a little late for you to start worrying about doing what an Aes Sedai thinks, isn't it? Now, are you coming?"

"aɪ kən faɪn ðə dʌnʒən wɪθaʊt ju. ðeɪ ɑɹ lʊkɪŋ fəɹ mi, əɹ wɪl bi, ən ɪt woʊn dʒju ɛni ɡʊd tə bi faʊnd wɪð mi."

"I can find the dungeon without you. They are looking for me, or will be, and it won't do you any good to be found with me."

"wɪθaʊt mi," ʃi sɛd dʒɹaɪli, "jul laɪkli tʃɹɪp oʊvɝ jəɹ oʊn fiɾ ən fɔl ɪn ði æmɪɝlɪn sits læp, ðən kənfɛs ɛvɹiθɪŋ waɪl tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə tɔk jəɹ weɪ aʊɾ ʌv ɪt."

"Without me," she said dryly, "you'll likely trip over your own feet and fall in the Amyrlin Seat's lap, then confess everything while trying to talk your way out of it."

"blʌɾ ən æʃəz, jə ɔt tə bi ɪn ðə wɪmənz sɝkəl bæk hoʊm. ɪf mɛn wɝ ɔl əz fʌmbəl-fʊɾɪd ən hɛlpləs əz jə sim tə θɪŋk, wid nɛvɝ - "

"Blood and ashes, you ought to be in the Women's Circle back home. If men were all as fumble-footed and helpless as you seem to think, we'd never - "

"ɑɹ jə gɑnə stæn hɪɹ tɔkɪŋ əntɪl ðeɪ də faɪn ju? pɪk ʌp jəɹ θɪŋz, ɹænd, ən kʌm wɪð mi." nɑt weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ən ænsɝ, ʃi spʌn ɝaʊn ən stɑɹɾəd ɔf daʊn ðə hɔl. mʌɾɝɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ, hi ɹɪlʌktənli oʊbeɪd.

"Are you going to stand here talking until they do find you? Pick up your things, Rand, and come with me." Not waiting for an answer, she spun around and started off down the hall. Muttering under his breath, he reluctantly obeyed.

ðəɹ wɝ fju pipəl - sɝvəns, meɪnli - ɪn ðə bæk weɪz ðeɪ tʊk, bʌt ɹænd hæd ðə filɪŋ ðət ðeɪ ɔl tʊk spɛʃəl noʊɾəs ə hɪm. nɑt noʊɾəs ʌv ə mæn bɝɾənd fəɹ ə dʒɝni, bʌɾ ə hɪm, ɹænd ælθɹ ɪn pɝtɪkjəlɝ. hi nu ɪt wɑz ɪz ɪmædʒəneɪʃən - hi hoʊpt ɪt wɑz - bʌɾ ivən soʊ, hi fɛl noʊ ɹɪlif wən ðeɪ stɑpt ɪn ə pæsədʒweɪ dip bɪniθ ðə kip, bɪfɔɹ ə tɔl dɔɹ wɪð ə smɔl aɪɝn ɡɹɪl sɛɾ ɪn ɪt, əz θɪkli stʃɹæpt wɪð aɪɝn əz ɛni ɪn ði aʊɾɝ wɔl. ə klæpɝ hʌŋ bɪloʊ ðə ɡɹɪl.

There were few people - servants, mainly - in the back ways they took, but Rand had the feeling that they all took special notice of him. Not notice of a man burdened for a journey, but of him, Rand al'Thor in particular. He knew it was his imagination - he hoped it was - but even so, he felt no relief when they stopped in a passageway deep beneath the keep, before a tall door with a small iron grill set in it, as thickly strapped with iron as any in the outer wall. A clapper hung below the grill.

θɹu ðə ɡɹɪl ɹænd kəd si bɛɹ wɔlz, ən tu tɑp-nɑɾɪd soʊlʒɝz sɪɾɪŋ bæɹhɛɾɪd əɾ ə teɪbəl wɪð ə læmp ɑn ɪt. wʌn ə ðə mɛn wɑz ʃɑɹpənɪŋ ə dæɡɝ wɪð lɔŋ, sloʊ stʃɹoʊks ʌv ə stoʊn. hɪz stʃɹoʊks nɛvɝ fɔltɝd wən ɛɡwin ɹæpt wɪð ðə klæpɝ, ə ʃɑɹp klæŋ ʌv aɪɝn ɑn aɪɝn. ði ʌðɝ mæn, hɪz feɪs flæɾ ən sʌlən, lʊkt ət ðə dɔɹ əz ɪf kənsɪɾɝɪŋ bɪfɔɹ i faɪnəli ɹoʊz ən keɪm oʊvɝ. hi wɑz skwɑɾ ən stɑki, bɛɹli tɔl ɪnʌf tə lʊk θɹu ðə kɹɔs-hætʃt bɑɹz.

Through the grill Rand could see bare walls, and two top-knotted soldiers sitting bareheaded at a table with a lamp on it. One of the men was sharpening a dagger with long, slow strokes of a stone. His strokes never faltered when Egwene rapped with the clapper, a sharp clang of iron on iron. The other man, his face flat and sullen, looked at the door as if considering before he finally rose and came over. He was squat and stocky, barely tall enough to look through the cross-hatched bars.

"wʌt dʒju wɑnt? oʊ, ɪts jə əɡɛn, ɡɝl. kʌm tə si jəɹ dɑɹkfɹɛnd? huz ðæt?" hi meɪd noʊ muv tə oʊpən ðə dɔɹ.

"What do you want? Oh, it's you again, girl. Come to see your Darkfriend? Who's that?" He made no move to open the door.

"hiz ə fɹɛn ə maɪn, tʃæŋɡʌ. hi wɑns tə si mæstɝ feɪn, tu."

"He's a friend of mine, Changu. He wants to see Master Fain, too."

ðə mæn stʌɾid ɹænd, hɪz ʌpɝ lɪp kwɪvɝɪŋ bæk tə bɛɹ tiθ. ɹænd dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ɪt wɑz səpoʊz tə bi ə smaɪl. "wɛl," tʃæŋɡʌ sɛd faɪnəli. "wɛl. tɔl, ɑɹən ju? tɔl. ən fænsi dʒɹɛs fəɹ jəɹ kaɪnd. sʌmbɑɾi kætʃ jə jʌŋ ɪn ði istɝn mɑɹtʃɪz ən teɪm ju?" hi slæm bæk ðə boʊls ən jæŋkt oʊpən ðə dɔɹ. "wɛl, kʌm ɪn ɪf jəɹ kʌmɪŋ." hi tʊk ɑn ə mɑkɪŋ toʊn. "teɪk kɛɹ nɑt tə bʌmp jəɹ hɛd, maɪ lɔɹd."

The man studied Rand, his upper lip quivering back to bare teeth. Rand did not think it was supposed to be a smile. "Well," Changu said finally. "Well. Tall, aren't you? Tall. And fancy dressed for your kind. Somebody catch you young in the Eastern Marches and tame you?" He slammed back the bolts and yanked open the door. "Well, come in if you're coming." He took on a mocking tone. "Take care not to bump your head, my Lord."

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ deɪnʒɝ ə ðæt; ðə dɔɹ wɑz tɔl ɪnʌf fəɹ lɔɪəl. ɹænd fɑloʊɾ ɛɡwin ɪn, fɹaʊnɪŋ ən wʌndɝɪŋ ɪf ðɪs tʃæŋɡʌ mɛn tə meɪk səm sɔɹɾ ə tʃɹʌbəl. hi wɑz ðə fɝst ɹud ʃaɪnɝən ɹænd hæd mɛt; ivən mæsimə wɑz oʊnli koʊld, nɑt ɹɪli ɹud. bʌt ðə fɛloʊ dʒʌs bæŋ ðə dɔɹ ʃʌɾ ən ɹæm ðə hɛvi boʊls hoʊm, ðən wɛn tə səm ʃɛlvz bɪɑn ði ɛn ə ðə teɪbəl ən tʊk wʌn ə ðə læmps ðɛɹ. ði ʌðɝ mæn nɛvɝ sist stʃɹɑpɪŋ ɪz naɪf, nɛvɝ ivən lʊkt ʌp fɹəm ɪt. ðə ɹum wɑz bɛɹ ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə teɪbəl ən bɛntʃɪz ən ʃɛlvz, wɪð stʃɹɔ ɑn ðə flɔɹ ən ənʌðɝ aɪɝn-baʊn dɔɹ liɾɪŋ dipɝ ɪn.

There was no danger of that; the door was tall enough for Loial. Rand followed Egwene in, frowning and wondering if this Changu meant to make some sort of trouble. He was the first rude Shienaran Rand had met; even Masema was only cold, not really rude. But the fellow just banged the door shut and rammed the heavy bolts home, then went to some shelves beyond the end of the table and took one of the lamps there. The other man never ceased stropping his knife, never even looked up from it. The room was bare except for the table and benches and shelves, with straw on the floor and another iron-bound door leading deeper in.

"jul wɑn səm laɪt, woʊn ju," tʃæŋɡʌ sɛd, "ɪn ðəɹ ɪn ðə dɑɹk wɪð jəɹ dɑɹkfɹɛn fɹɛnd." hi læft, kɔɹs ən hjumɝləs, ən lɪt ðə læmp. "hiz weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ju." hi θɹʌs ðə læmp əɾ ɛɡwin, ən əndɪd ði ɪnɝ dɔɹ ɔlmoʊst iɡɝli. "weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ju. ɪn ðɛɹ, ɪn ðə dɑɹk."

"You'll want some light, won't you," Changu said, "in there in the dark with your Darkfriend friend." He laughed, coarse and humorless, and lit the lamp. "He's waiting for you." He thrust the lamp at Egwene, and undid the inner door almost eagerly. "Waiting for you. In there, in the dark."

ɹænd pɔzd ənizəli ət ðə blæknəs bɪɑnd, ən tʃæŋɡʌ ɡɹɪnɪŋ bɪhaɪnd, bʌɾ ɛɡwin kɑɾ ɪz sliv ən pʊld ɪm ɪn. ðə dɔɹ slæmd, ɔlmoʊs kætʃɪŋ ɪz hil; ðə lætʃ bɑɹz klæŋd ʃʌt. ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli ðə laɪɾ ə ðə læmp, ə smɔl pul ɝaʊn əm ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs.

Rand paused uneasily at the blackness beyond, and Changu grinning behind, but Egwene caught his sleeve and pulled him in. The door slammed, almost catching his heel; the latch bars clanged shut. There was only the light of the lamp, a small pool around them in the darkness.

"ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ hɪl lɛɾ əs aʊt?" hi æskt. ðə mæn hæd nɛvɝ ivən lʊkt əɾ ɪz sɔɹɾ əɹ baʊ, hi ɹilaɪzd, nɛvɝ æskt wʌt wɑz ɪn ɪz bʌndəlz. "ðeɪ ɑɹən vɛɹi ɡʊd ɡɑɹdz. wi kəd bi hɪɹ tə bɹeɪk feɪn fɹi fəɹ ɔl i noʊz."

"Are you sure he'll let us out?" he asked. The man had never even looked at his sword or bow, he realized, never asked what was in his bundles. "They aren't very good guards. We could be here to break Fain free for all he knows."

"ðeɪ noʊ mi bɛɾɝ ðən ðæt," ʃi sɛd, bʌt ʃi saʊndəd tʃɹʌbəld, ən ʃi æɾəd, "ðeɪ sim wɝs ɛvɹi taɪm aɪ kʌm. ɔl ðə ɡɑɹdz du. minɝ, ən mɔɹ sʌlən. tʃæŋɡʌ toʊl dʒoʊks ðə fɝs taɪm aɪ keɪm, ən naɪdaʊ nɛvɝ ivən spiks ɛnimɔɹ. bʌɾ aɪ səpoʊz wɝkɪŋ ɪn ə pleɪs laɪk ðɪs kænt ɡɪv ə mæn ə laɪt hɑɹt. meɪbi ɪts dʒʌs mi. ðɪs pleɪs dʌz nɑt də maɪ hɑɹɾ ɛni ɡʊd, iðɝ." dɪspaɪɾ əɹ wɝdz, ʃi dʒɹu hɪm kɑnfəɾəntli ɪndə ðə blæk. hi kɛpt ɪz fɹi hæn ɑn ɪz sɔɹd.

"They know me better than that," she said, but she sounded troubled, and she added, "They seem worse every time I come. All the guards do. Meaner, and more sullen. Changu told jokes the first time I came, and Nidao never even speaks anymore. But I suppose working in a place like this can't give a man a light heart. Maybe it is just me. This place does not do my heart any good, either." Despite her words, she drew him confidently into the black. He kept his free hand on his sword.

ðə peɪl læmplaɪt ʃoʊɾ ə waɪd hɔl wɪð flæɾ aɪɝn ɡɹɪlz tə iðɝ saɪd, fɹʌntɪŋ stoʊn-wɔl sɛlz. oʊnli tu ʌv ðə sɛlz ðeɪ pæs hɛl pɹɪznɝz. ði ɑkjəpəns sæɾ ʌp ɑn ðɛɹ nɛɹoʊ kɑts əz ðə laɪt stʃɹʌk ðɛm, ʃildɪŋ ðɛɹ aɪz wɪð ðɛɹ hænz, ɡlɛɹɪŋ bɪtwin ðɛɹ fɪŋɡɝz. ivən wɪð ðɛɹ feɪsəz hɪɾən, ɹænd wɑz ʃʊɹ ðeɪ wɝ ɡlɛɹɪŋ. ðɛɹ aɪz ɡlɪɾɝd ɪn ðə læmplaɪt.

The pale lamplight showed a wide hall with flat iron grills to either side, fronting stone-walled cells. Only two of the cells they passed held prisoners. The occupants sat up on their narrow cots as the light struck them, shielding their eyes with their hands, glaring between their fingers. Even with their faces hidden, Rand was sure they were glaring. Their eyes glittered in the lamplight.

"ðæt wʌn laɪks tə dʒɹɪŋk ən faɪt," ɛɡwin mɝmɝd, ɪndəkeɪɾɪŋ ə bɝli fɛloʊ wɪð sʌŋkən nʌkəlz. "ðɪs taɪm i ɹɛk ðə kɑmən ɹum ʌv ən ɪn ɪn ðə taʊn sɪŋɡəl-hændəd, ən hɝt səm mɛn bædli." ði ʌðɝ pɹɪznɝ wɔɹ ə ɡoʊld-ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd koʊt wɪð waɪd slivz, ən loʊ, ɡlimɪŋ buts. "hi tʃɹaɪd tə liv ðə sɪɾi wɪθaʊt sɛɾəlɪŋ ɪz ɪn bɪl" - ʃi snɪf laʊdli ət ðæt; hɝ fɑðɝ wɑz ən ɪnkipɝ əz wɛl əz meɪɝ ʌv ɛmənz fild - "nɔɹ peɪɪŋ hæf ə dʌzən ʃɑpkipɝz ən mɝtʃəns wʌɾ i oʊd."

"That one likes to drink and fight," Egwene murmured, indicating a burly fellow with sunken knuckles. "This time he wrecked the common room of an inn in the town single-handed, and hurt some men badly." The other prisoner wore a gold-embroidered coat with wide sleeves, and low, gleaming boots. "He tried to leave the city without settling his inn bill" - she sniffed loudly at that; her father was an innkeeper as well as Mayor of Emond's Field - "nor paying half a dozen shopkeepers and merchants what he owed."

ðə mɛn snɑɹəld ət ðɛm, ɡʌɾɝəl kɝsɪz əz bæɾ əz ɛni ɹænd hæd hɝd fɹəm mɝtʃəns' ɡɑɹdz.

The men snarled at them, guttural curses as bad as any Rand had heard from merchants' guards.

"ðeɪ ɡɹoʊ wɝs ɛvɹi deɪ, tu," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə taɪt vɔɪs, ən kwɪkən əɹ stɛp.

"They grow worse every day, too," she said in a tight voice, and quickened her step.

ʃi wɑz ɪnʌf əhɛɾ ə hɪm wən ðeɪ ɹitʃt pdən feɪnz sɛl, ət ðə vɛɹi ɛnd, ðət ɹænd wɑz aʊɾ ə ðə laɪɾ ɪntaɪɝli. hi stɑp ðɛɹ, ɪn ðə ʃædoʊz bɪhaɪn əɹ læmp.

She was enough ahead of him when they reached Padan Fain's cell, at the very end, that Rand was out of the light entirely. He stopped there, in the shadows behind her lamp.

feɪn wɑz sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ɪz kɑt, linɪŋ fɔɹwɝɾ ɪkspɛktənli əz ɪf weɪɾɪŋ, dʒʌst əz tʃæŋɡʌ hæd sɛd. hi wɑz ə boʊni, ʃɑɹp-aɪd mæn, wɪð lɔŋ ɑɹmz ən ə bɪɡ noʊz, ivən mɔɹ ɡɔnt naʊ ðən ɹænd ɹɪmɛmbɝd. nɑt ɡɔn fɹəm ðə dʌnʒən - ðə fud hɪɹ wɑz ðə seɪm əz ðə sɝvəns eɪt, ən nɑɾ ivən ðə wɝs pɹɪznɝ wɑz ʃɔɹɾɪd - bʌt fɹəm wʌɾ i hæd dʌn bɪfɔɹ kʌmɪŋ tə fæl dæɹə.

Fain was sitting on his cot, leaning forward expectantly as if waiting, just as Changu had said. He was a bony, sharp-eyed man, with long arms and a big nose, even more gaunt now than Rand remembered. Not gaunt from the dungeon - the food here was the same as the servants ate, and not even the worst prisoner was shorted - but from what he had done before coming to Fal Dara.

ðə saɪɾ ə hɪm bɹɔt bæk mɛmɹiz ɹænd wəd dʒʌst əz sun əv dʌn wɪθaʊt. feɪn ɑn ðə siɾ ə hɪz bɪɡ pɛdlɝz wæɡən wilɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə wæɡən bɹɪdʒ, ɝaɪvɪŋ ɪn ɛmənz fil ðə deɪ ʌv wɪntɝnaɪt. ən ɑn wɪntɝnaɪt ðə tʃɹɑləks keɪm, kɪlɪŋ ən bɝnɪŋ, hʌntɪŋ. hʌntɪŋ θɹi jʌŋ mɛn, mɔɪɹeɪn hæd sɛd. hʌntɪŋ mi, ɪf ðeɪ oʊnli nu ɪt, ən juzɪŋ feɪn fəɹ ðɛɹ tʃɹeɪl haʊnd.

The sight of him brought back memories Rand would just as soon have done without. Fain on the seat of his big peddler's wagon wheeling across the Wagon Bridge, arriving in Emond's Field the day of Winternight. And on Winternight the Trollocs came, killing and burning, hunting. Hunting three young men, Moiraine had said. Hunting me, if they only knew it, and using Fain for their trail hound.

feɪn stʊɾ əɾ ɛɡwinz əpɹoʊtʃ, nɑt ʃildɪŋ ɪz aɪz əɹ ivən blɪŋkɪŋ ət ðə laɪt. hi smaɪld ət hɝ, ə smaɪl ðət tʌtʃt oʊnli hɪz lɪps, ðən ɹeɪzd ɪz aɪz əbʌv əɹ hɛd. lʊkɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ ət ɹænd, hɪɾən ɪn ðə blæknəs bɪhaɪn ðə laɪt, hi pɔɪntəɾ ə lɔŋ fɪŋɡɝ ət hɪm. "aɪ fil jə ðɛɹ, haɪɾɪŋ, ɹænd ælθɹ," hi sɛd, ɔlmoʊs kɹunɪŋ. "ju kæn haɪd, nɑt fɹəm mi, ən nɑt fɹəm ðɛm. jə θɔɾ ɪt wɑz oʊvɝ, dɪd jə nɑt? bʌt ðə bæɾəlz nɛvɝ dʌn, ælθɹ. ðeɪ ɑɹ kʌmɪŋ fəɹ mi, ən ðəɹ kʌmɪŋ fəɹ ju, ən ðə wɔɹ ɡoʊz ɑn. wɛðɝ jə lɪv əɹ daɪ, ɪts nɛvɝ oʊvɝ fəɹ ju. nɛvɝ." sʌɾənli hi bɪɡæn tə tʃænt.

Fain stood at Egwene's approach, not shielding his eyes or even blinking at the light. He smiled at her, a smile that touched only his lips, then raised his eyes above her head. Looking straight at Rand, hidden in the blackness behind the light, he pointed a long finger at him. "I feel you there, hiding, Rand al'Thor," he said, almost crooning. "You can't hide, not from me, and not from them. You thought it was over, did you not? But the battle's never done, al'Thor. They are coming for me, and they're coming for you, and the war goes on. Whether you live or die, it's never over for you. Never." Suddenly he began to chant.

"sun kʌmz ðə deɪ ɔl ʃæl bi fɹi.

"Soon comes the day all shall be free.

ivən ju, ən ivən mi.

Even you, and even me.

sun kʌmz ðə deɪ ɔl ʃæl daɪ.

Soon comes the day all shall die.

ʃʊɹli ju, bʌt nɛvɝ aɪ."

Surely you, but never I."

hi lɛɾ ɪz ɑɹm fɔl, ən ɪz aɪz ɹoʊz tə stɛɹ ɪntɛnli əɾ ən æŋɡəl ʌp ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs. ə kɹʊkəd ɡɹɪn twɪstɪŋ ɪz maʊθ, hi tʃʌkəl dip ɪn ɪz θɹoʊɾ əz ɪf wʌtɛvɝ i sɔ wɑz əmjuzɪŋ. "mɔɹɾɪθ noʊz mɔɹ ðən ɔl ə ju. mɔɹɾɪθ noʊz."

He let his arm fall, and his eyes rose to stare intently at an angle up into the darkness. A crooked grin twisting his mouth, he chuckled deep in his throat as if whatever he saw was amusing. "Mordeth knows more than all of you. Mordeth knows."

ɛɡwin bækt əweɪ fɹəm ðə sɛl əntɪl ʃi ɹitʃt ɹænd, ən oʊnli ði ɛdʒ ə ðə laɪt tʌtʃt ðə bɑɹz ə feɪnz sɛl. dɑɹknəs hɪd ðə pɛdlɝ, bʌt ðeɪ kəd stɪl hɪɹ ɪz tʃʌkəlz. ivən əneɪbəl tə si hɪm, ɹænd wɑz ʃʊɹ feɪn wɑz stɪl piɹɪŋ ɔf ət nʌθɪŋ.

Egwene backed away from the cell until she reached Rand, and only the edge of the light touched the bars of Fain's cell. Darkness hid the peddler, but they could still hear his chuckles. Even unable to see him, Rand was sure Fain was still peering off at nothing.

wɪð ə ʃɪvɝ, hi pɹaɪɾ ɪz fɪŋɡɝz ɔf ɪz sɔɹd hɪlt. "laɪt!" hi sɛd hɔɹsli. "ðɪs ɪz wʌt jə kɔl biɪŋ laɪk i juz tə bi?"

With a shiver, he pried his fingers off his sword hilt. "Light!" he said hoarsely. "This is what you call being like he used to be?"

"səmtaɪmz hiz bɛɾɝ, ən səmtaɪmz wɝs." ɛɡwinz vɔɪs wɑz ənstɛɾi. "ðɪs ɪz wɝs - mʌtʃ wɝs ðən juʒəwəl."

"Sometimes he's better, and sometimes worse." Egwene's voice was unsteady. "This is worse - much worse than usual."

"wʌɾ ɪz i siɪŋ, aɪ wʌndɝ. hiz mæd, stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ə stoʊn silɪŋ ɪn ðə dɑɹk." ɪf ðə stoʊn wɝn ðɛɹ, hid bi lʊkɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ ət ðə wɪmənz əpɑɹtməns. wɛɹ mɔɪɹeɪn ɪz, ən ði æmɪɝlɪn sit. hi ʃɪvɝɾ əɡɛn. "hiz mæd."

"What is he seeing, I wonder. He's mad, staring at a stone ceiling in the dark." If the stone weren't there, he'd be looking straight at the women's apartments. Where Moiraine is, and the Amyrlin Seat. He shivered again. "He's mad."

"ðɪs wɑz nɑɾ ə ɡʊɾ aɪdiə, ɹænd." lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ ət ðə sɛl, ʃi dʒɹu hɪm əweɪ fɹəm ɪɾ ən loʊɝɾ əɹ vɔɪs əz ɪf əfɹeɪd feɪn maɪɾ oʊvɝhɪɹ. feɪnz tʃʌkəlz fɑloʊd ðɛm. "ivən ɪf ðeɪ doʊn lʊk hɪɹ, aɪ kænɑt steɪ hɪɹ wɪð ɪm laɪk ðɪs, ən aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk jə ʃʊd, iðɝ. ðəɹ ɪz sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪm tədeɪ ðæt. . . ." ʃi dʒɹu ə ʃeɪki bɹɛθ. "ðɛɹ ɪz wʌn pleɪs ivən seɪfɝ fɹəm sɝtʃ ðən hɪɹ. aɪ dɪd nɑt mɛnʃən ɪt bɪfɔɹ kəz ɪt wɑz iziɝ tə ɡɛt jə ɪn hɪɹ, bʌt ðəl nɛvɝ lʊk ɪn ðə wɪmənz əpɑɹtməns. nɛvɝ."

"This was not a good idea, Rand." Looking over her shoulder at the cell, she drew him away from it and lowered her voice as if afraid Fain might overhear. Fain's chuckles followed them. "Even if they don't look here, I cannot stay here with him like this, and I do not think you should, either. There is something about him today that. . . ." She drew a shaky breath. "There is one place even safer from search than here. I did not mention it before because it was easier to get you in here, but they will never look in the women's apartments. Never."

"ðə wɪmənz . . . ! ɛɡwin, feɪn meɪ bi mæd, bʌt jəɹ mæɾɝ. jə kæn haɪd fɹəm hɔɹnəts ɪn ə hɔɹnəts' nɛst."

"The women's . . . ! Egwene, Fain may be mad, but you're madder. You can't hide from hornets in a hornets' nest."

"wʌt bɛɾɝ pleɪs? wʌɾ ɪz ðə wʌn pɑɹɾ ə ðə kip noʊ mæn wɪl ɛntɝ wɪθaʊɾ ə wʊmənz ɪnvɪteɪʃən, nɑɾ ivən lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ? wʌɾ ɪz ðə wʌn pleɪs noʊ wʌn wəɾ ɛvɝ θɪŋk tə lʊk fəɹ ə mæn?"

"What better place? What is the one part of the keep no man will enter without a woman's invitation, not even Lord Agelmar? What is the one place no one would ever think to look for a man?"

"wʌɾ ɪz ðə wʌn pleɪs ɪn ðə kip ʃʊɹ tə bi fʊl ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ? ɪts kɹeɪzi, ɛɡwin."

"What is the one place in the keep sure to be full of Aes Sedai? It is crazy, Egwene."

poʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪz bʌndəlz, ʃi spoʊk əz ɪf ɪt wɝ ɔl dɪsaɪɾɪd. "ju mʌst ɹæp jəɹ sɔɹɾ ən baʊ ɪn jəɹ kloʊk, ən ðən ɪɾəl lʊk əz ɪf jə ɑɹ kæɹiɪŋ θɪŋz fəɹ mi. ɪt ʃəd nɑt bi tu hɑɹd tə faɪn jə ə dʒɝkɪn ən ə ʃɝt ðəɾ ɪzən soʊ pɹɪɾi. jəl əv tə stup, ðoʊ."

Poking at his bundles, she spoke as if it were all decided. "You must wrap your sword and bow in your cloak, and then it will look as if you are carrying things for me. It should not be too hard to find you a jerkin and a shirt that isn't so pretty. You will have to stoop, though."

"aɪ toʊl ju, aɪ woʊn də ɪt."

"I told you, I won't do it."

"sɪns jəɹ æktɪŋ stʌbɝn əz ə mjul, jə ʃəd teɪk ɹaɪt tə pleɪɪŋ maɪ bist ə bɝɾən. ənlɛs jə wəd ɹɪli ɹæðɝ steɪ daʊn hɪɹ wɪð hɪm."

"Since you're acting stubborn as a mule, you should take right to playing my beast of burden. Unless you would really rather stay down here with him."

feɪnz læfɪŋ wɪspɝ keɪm θɹu ðə blæk ʃædoʊz. "ðə bæɾəlz nɛvɝ dʌn, ælθɹ. mɔɹɾɪθ noʊz."

Fain's laughing whisper came through the black shadows. "The battle's never done, al'Thor. Mordeth knows."

"aɪɾ əv ə bɛɾɝ tʃæns dʒʌmpɪŋ ɔf ðə wɔl," ɹænd mʌɾɝd. bʌɾ i ənsləŋ ɪz bʌndəlz ən sɛɾ əbaʊt ɹæpɪŋ sɔɹɾ ən baʊ ən kwɪvɝ əz ʃi hæd sədʒɛstəd.

"I'd have a better chance jumping off the wall," Rand muttered. But he unslung his bundles and set about wrapping sword and bow and quiver as she had suggested.

ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs, feɪn læft. "ɪts nɛvɝ oʊvɝ, ælθɹ. nɛvɝ."

In the darkness, Fain laughed. "It's never over, al'Thor. Never."


tʃæptɝ fɔɹ

sʌmənd


Summoned

əloʊn ɪn əɹ ɹumz ɪn ðə wɪmənz əpɑɹtməns, mɔɪɹeɪn ədʒʌstəd ðə ʃɔl, ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð kɝlɪŋ aɪvi ən ɡɹeɪpvaɪnz, ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz ən stʌɾid ði ɪfɛkt ɪn ðə tɔl fɹeɪm mɪɹɝ stændɪŋ ɪn ə kɔɹnɝ. hɝ lɑɹdʒ, dɑɹk aɪz kəɾ əpɪɹ əz ʃɑɹp əz ə hɔks wən ʃi wɑz æŋɡɹi. ðeɪ sim tə pɪɹs ðə sɪlvɝd ɡlæs, naʊ. ɪt wɑz oʊnli hæpənstæns ðət ʃi hæd hæd ðə ʃɔl ɪn əɹ sæɾəlbæɡz wən ʃi keɪm tə fæl dæɹə. wɪð ðə bleɪzɪŋ waɪt fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn sɛntɝɾ ɑn ðə wɛɹɝz bæk ən lɔŋ fɹɪnʒ kʌlɝd tə ʃoʊ hɝ ədʒɑ - mɔɪɹeɪnz wɑz əz blu əz ə mɔɹnɪŋ skaɪ - ðə ʃɔlz wɝ sɛldəm wɔɹn aʊtsaɪd tɑɹ vəlɑn, ən ivən ðəɹ juʒəwəli oʊnli ɪnsaɪd ðə waɪt taʊɝ. lɪɾəl ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn bɪsaɪdz ə miɾɪŋ ə ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ kɔl fəɹ ðə fɔɹmæləɾi ʌv ðə ʃɔlz, ən bɪɑn ðə ʃaɪnɪŋ wɔlz ə saɪɾ ə ðə fleɪm wəd sɛn tu mɛni pipəl ɹʌnɪŋ, tə haɪɾ əɹ pɝhæps tə fɛtʃ ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt. eɪ waɪtkloʊks æɹoʊ wɑz əz feɪɾəl tə ən ɛɛs sədaɪ əz tə ɛniwʌn ɛls, ən ðə tʃɪlʒɹən wɝ tu waɪli tə lɛɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ si ðə boʊmən bɪfɔɹ ði æɹoʊ stʃɹʌk, waɪl ʃi stɪl maɪt də sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt. mɔɪɹeɪn hæd sɝɾənli nɛvɝ ɪkspɛktəd tə wɛɹ ðə ʃɔl ɪn fæl dæɹə. bʌt fəɹ ən ɑɾiəns wɪð ði æmɪɝlɪn, ðəɹ wɝ pɹəpɹaɪəɾiz tə əbzɝv.

Alone in her rooms in the women's apartments, Moiraine adjusted the shawl, embroidered with curling ivy and grapevines, on her shoulders and studied the effect in the tall frame mirror standing in a corner. Her large, dark eyes could appear as sharp as a hawk's when she was angry. They seemed to pierce the silvered glass, now. It was only happenstance that she had had the shawl in her saddlebags when she came to Fal Dara. With the blazing white Flame of Tar Valon centered on the wearer's back and long fringe colored to show her Ajah - Moiraine's was as blue as a morning sky - the shawls were seldom worn outside Tar Valon, and even there usually only inside the White Tower. Little in Tar Valon besides a meeting of the Hall of the Tower called for the formality of the shawls, and beyond the Shining Walls a sight of the Flame would send too many people running, to hide or perhaps to fetch the Children of the Light. A Whitecloak's arrow was as fatal to an Aes Sedai as to anyone else, and the Children were too wily to let an Aes Sedai see the bowman before the arrow struck, while she still might do something about it. Moiraine had certainly never expected to wear the shawl in Fal Dara. But for an audience with the Amyrlin, there were proprieties to observe.

ʃi wɑz slɛndɝ ən nɑɾ əɾ ɔl tɔl, ən smuð-tʃikt ɛɛs sədaɪ eɪɡləsnəs ɔfən meɪɾ əɹ əpɪɹ jʌŋɡɝ ðən ʃi wɑz, bʌt mɔɪɹeɪn hæɾ ə kəmændɪŋ ɡɹeɪs ən kɑm pɹɛzəns ðət kəd dɑməneɪɾ ɛni ɡæðɝɪŋ. ə mænɝ ɪnɡɹeɪnd ɡɹoʊɪŋ ʌp ɪn ðə ɹɔɪəl pæləs ə kɛɹhin hæd bɪn haɪɾənd, nɑt səbmɝdʒd, baɪ stɪl mɔɹ jɪɹz əz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. ʃi nu ʃi maɪt niɾ ɛvɹi bɪɾ ʌv ɪt tədeɪ. jɛt mʌtʃ ə ðə kɑm wɑz ɑn ðə sɝfəs, tədeɪ. ðəɹ mʌs bi tʃɹʌbəl, əɹ ʃi wəd nɑɾ əv kʌm hɝsɛlf, ʃi θɔt fəɹ ət lis ðə tɛnθ taɪm. bʌt bɪɑn ðət leɪ ə θaʊzən kwɛstʃənz mɔɹ. wʌt tʃɹʌbəl, ən u dɪd ʃi tʃuz tə əkʌmpəni hɝ? waɪ hɪɹ? waɪ naʊ? ɪt kænɑt bi əlaʊd tə ɡoʊ ɹɔŋ naʊ.

She was slender and not at all tall, and smooth-cheeked Aes Sedai agelessness often made her appear younger than she was, but Moiraine had a commanding grace and calm presence that could dominate any gathering. A manner ingrained growing up in the Royal Palace of Cairhien had been heightened, not submerged, by still more years as an Aes Sedai. She knew she might need every bit of it today. Yet much of the calm was on the surface, today. There must be trouble, or she would not have come herself, she thought for at least the tenth time. But beyond that lay a thousand questions more. What trouble, and who did she choose to accompany her? Why here? Why now? It cannot be allowed to go wrong now.

ðə ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ ɑn əɹ ɹaɪt hæn kɑt ðə laɪt dʌli əz ʃi tʌtʃt ðə dɛləkət ɡoʊldən tʃeɪn fæsən ɪn əɹ dɑɹk hɛɹ, wɪtʃ hʌŋ ɪn weɪvz tə hɝ ʃoʊldɝz. ə smɔl, klɪɹ blu stoʊn dæŋɡəl fɹəm ðə tʃeɪn, ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə hɝ fɔɹhɛd. mɛni ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ nu ʌv ðə tʃɹɪks ʃi kəd də juzɪŋ ðət stoʊn əz ə foʊkəs. ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə pɑlɪʃt bɪɾ ə blu kɹɪstəl, dʒʌst sʌmθɪŋ ə jʌŋ ɡɝl hæd juzd ɪn əɹ fɝs lɝnɪŋ, wɪð noʊ wʌn tə ɡaɪd hɝ. ðət ɡɝl hæd ɹɪmɛmbɝd teɪlz ʌv æŋɡɹil ən ivən mɔɹ paʊɝfəl sɑŋɡɹil - ðoʊz feɪbəld ɹɛmnəns ə ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz ðəɾ əlaʊɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ tə tʃænəl mɔɹ ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ ðən ɛni kəd seɪfli hændəl əneɪɾɪd - ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ən θɔt səm sətʃ foʊkəs wɑz ɹikwaɪɝd tə tʃænəl əɾ ɔl. hɝ sɪstɝz ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ nu ə fju ʌv əɹ tʃɹɪks, ən səspɛktəɾ ʌðɝz, ɪnkluɾɪŋ səm ðət dɪd nɑɾ ɪɡzɪst, səm ðət hæd ʃɑkt əɹ wən ʃi lɝn ə ðɛm. ðə θɪŋz ʃi dɪd wɪð ðə stoʊn wɝ sɪmpəl ən smɔl, ɪf əkeɪʒənəli jusfəl; ðə kaɪn ə tʃaɪld wəɾ ɪmædʒən. bʌɾ ɪf ðə ɹɔŋ wɪmən hæɾ əkʌmpənid ði æmɪɝlɪn, ðə kɹɪstəl maɪt pʊɾ əm ɔf bæləns, kəz ə ðə teɪlz.

The Great Serpent ring on her right hand caught the light dully as she touched the delicate golden chain fastened in her dark hair, which hung in waves to her shoulders. A small, clear blue stone dangled from the chain, in the middle of her forehead. Many in the White Tower knew of the tricks she could do using that stone as a focus. It was only a polished bit of blue crystal, just something a young girl had used in her first learning, with no one to guide her. That girl had remembered tales of angreal and even more powerful sa'angreal - those fabled remnants of the Age of Legends that allowed Aes Sedai to channel more of the One Power than any could safely handle unaided - remembered and thought some such focus was required to channel at all. Her sisters in the White Tower knew a few of her tricks, and suspected others, including some that did not exist, some that had shocked her when she learned of them. The things she did with the stone were simple and small, if occasionally useful; the kind a child would imagine. But if the wrong women had accompanied the Amyrlin, the crystal might put them off balance, because of the tales.

ə ɹæpəd, ɪnsɪstənt nɑkɪŋ keɪm ət ðə tʃeɪmbɝ dɔɹ. noʊ ʃaɪnɝən wəd nɑk ðət weɪ, nɑɾ əɾ ɛniwʌnz dɔɹ, bʌt list ʌv ɔl hɝz. ʃi ɹɪmeɪn lʊkɪŋ ɪndə ðə mɪɹɝ əntɪl əɹ aɪz stɛɹd bæk sɝinəli, ɔl θɔt hɪɾən ɪn ðɛɹ dɑɹk dɛpθs. ʃi tʃɛk ðə sɑf lɛðɝ paʊtʃ hæŋɪŋ əɾ əɹ bɛlt. wʌtɛvɝ tʃɹʌbəlz bɹɔɾ əɹ aʊɾ ə tɑɹ vəlɑn, ʃɪl fɝɡɛɾ əm wən aɪ leɪ ðɪs tʃɹʌbəl bɪfɔɹ hɝ. ə sɛkən θʌmpɪŋ, ivən mɔɹ vɪɡɝəs ðən ðə fɝst, saʊndəd bɪfɔɹ ʃi kɹɔs ðə ɹum ən oʊpən ðə dɔɹ wɪð ə kɑm smaɪl fəɹ ðə tu wɪmən u hæd kʌm fəɹ hɝ.

A rapid, insistent knocking came at the chamber door. No Shienaran would knock that way, not at anyone's door, but least of all hers. She remained looking into the mirror until her eyes stared back serenely, all thought hidden in their dark depths. She checked the soft leather pouch hanging at her belt. Whatever troubles brought her out of Tar Valon, she will forget them when I lay this trouble before her. A second thumping, even more vigorous than the first, sounded before she crossed the room and opened the door with a calm smile for the two women who had come for her.

ʃi ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd əm boʊθ. dɑɹk-hɛɹɾ æneɪjə ɪn əɹ blu-fɹɪnd ʃɔl, ən fɛɹ-hɛɹd liɑnʒɹɪn ɪn əɹ ɹɛd. liɑnʒɹɪn, nɑɾ oʊnli jʌŋ-simɪŋ bʌt jʌŋ ən pɹɪɾi, wɪð ə dɑlz feɪs ən ə smɔl, pɛtʃələn maʊθ, hæɾ əɹ hæn ɹeɪz tə paʊn əɡɛn. hɝ dɑɹk bɹaʊz ən dɑɹkɝ aɪz wɝ ə ʃɑɹp kɑntʃɹæs tə ðə mʌltətuɾ ə peɪl hʌni bɹeɪdz bɹʌʃɪŋ əɹ ʃoʊldɝz, bʌt ðə kɑmbəneɪʃən wɑz nɑɾ ənkɑmən ɪn tæɹɑbən. boʊθ wɪmən wɝ tɔlɝ ðən mɔɪɹeɪn, ðoʊ liɑnʒɹɪn baɪ lɛs ðən ə hænd.

She recognized them both. Dark-haired Anaiya in her blue-fringed shawl, and fair-haired Liandrin in her red. Liandrin, not only young-seeming but young and pretty, with a doll's face and a small, petulant mouth, had her hand raised to pound again. Her dark brows and darker eyes were a sharp contrast to the multitude of pale honey braids brushing her shoulders, but the combination was not uncommon in Tarabon. Both women were taller than Moiraine, though Liandrin by less than a hand.

æneɪjəz blʌn feɪs bɹoʊk ɪndə ə smaɪl əz sun əz mɔɪɹeɪn oʊpən ðə dɔɹ. ðət smaɪl ɡeɪv əɹ ði oʊnli bjuɾi ʃi wəɾ ɛvɝ hæv, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɪnʌf; ɔlmoʊst ɛvɹiwʌn fɛl kʌmfɝɾɪd, seɪf ən spɛʃəl, wən æneɪjə smaɪld ət ðɛm. "ðə laɪt ʃaɪn ɑn ju, mɔɪɹeɪn. ɪts ɡʊd tə si jə əɡɛn. ɑɹ jə wɛl? ɪts bɪn soʊ lɔŋ."

Anaiya's blunt face broke into a smile as soon as Moiraine opened the door. That smile gave her the only beauty she would ever have, but it was enough; almost everyone felt comforted, safe and special, when Anaiya smiled at them. "The Light shine on you, Moiraine. It's good to see you again. Are you well? It has been so long."

"maɪ hɑɹɾ ɪz laɪɾɝ fəɹ jəɹ pɹɛzəns, æneɪjə." ðət wɑz sɝɾənli tʃɹu; ɪt wɑz ɡʊd tə noʊ ʃi hæɾ ət list wʌn fɹɛn əmʌŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hu hæd kʌm tə fæl dæɹə. "ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin ju."

"My heart is lighter for your presence, Anaiya." That was certainly true; it was good to know she had at least one friend among the Aes Sedai who had come to Fal Dara. "The Light illumine you."

liɑnʒɹɪnz maʊθ taɪɾənd, ən ʃi ɡeɪv əɹ ʃɔl ə twɪtʃ. "ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, ʃi ɹikwaɪɝz jəɹ pɹɛzəns, sɪstɝ." hɝ vɔɪs wɑz pɛtʃələnt, tu, ən koʊld-ɛdʒd. nɑt fəɹ mɔɪɹeɪnz seɪk, əɹ nɑt soʊlli; liɑnʒɹɪn ɔlweɪz saʊndəd dɪsæɾəsfaɪd wɪð sʌmθɪŋ. fɹaʊnɪŋ, ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə lʊk oʊvɝ mɔɪɹeɪnz ʃoʊldɝ ɪndə ðə ɹum. "ðɪs tʃeɪmbɝ, ɪts wɔɹɾɪd. wi kænɑɾ ɛntɝ. waɪ dʒju wɔɹɾ əɡɛns jəɹ sɪstɝz?"

Liandrin's mouth tightened, and she gave her shawl a twitch. "The Amyrlin Seat, she requires your presence, Sister." Her voice was petulant, too, and cold-edged.
