Not for Moiraine's sake, or not solely; Liandrin always sounded dissatisfied with something. Frowning, she tried to look over Moiraine's shoulder into the room. "This chamber, it is warded. We cannot enter. Why do you ward against your sisters?"

"əɡɛnst ɔl," mɔɪɹeɪn ɹɪplaɪd smuðli. "mɛni ʌv ðə sɝvɪŋ wɪmən ɑɹ kjʊɹiəs əbaʊɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən aɪ də nɑt wɑn əm pɔɪŋ θɹu maɪ ɹumz wən aɪm nɑt hɪɹ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid tə meɪk ə dɪstɪŋkʃən əntɪl naʊ." ʃi pʊl ðə dɔɹ ʃʌt bɪhaɪn hɝ, livɪŋ ɔl θɹi ʌv əm ɪn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ. "ʃæl wi ɡoʊ? wi mʌs nɑt kip ði æmɪɝlɪn weɪɾɪŋ."

"Against all," Moiraine replied smoothly. "Many of the serving women are curious about Aes Sedai, and I do not want them pawing through my rooms when I am not here. There was no need to make a distinction until now." She pulled the door shut behind her, leaving all three of them in the corridor. "Shall we go? We must not keep the Amyrlin waiting."

ʃi stɑɹɾəd daʊn ðə hɔlweɪ wɪð æneɪjə tʃæɾɪŋ əɾ əɹ saɪd. liɑnʒɹɪn stʊd fəɹ ə moʊmən stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə dɔɹ əz ɪf wʌndɝɪŋ wʌt mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz haɪɾɪŋ, ðən hɝid tə dʒɔɪn ði ʌðɝz. ʃi bɹækəɾɪd mɔɪɹeɪn, wɔkɪŋ əz stɪfli əz ə ɡɑɹd. æneɪjə mɪɹli wɔkt, kipɪŋ kʌmpəni. ðɛɹ slɪpɝd fʊtstɛps fɛl sɔfli ɑn θɪk-woʊvən kɑɹpəts wɪð sɪmpəl pæɾɝnz.

She started down the hallway with Anaiya chatting at her side. Liandrin stood for a moment staring at the door as if wondering what Moiraine was hiding, then hurried to join the others. She bracketed Moiraine, walking as stiffly as a guard. Anaiya merely walked, keeping company. Their slippered footsteps fell softly on thick-woven carpets with simple patterns.

lɪvɹid wɪmən kɝtsid dipli əz ðeɪ pæst, mɛni mɔɹ dipli ðən ðeɪ wəɾ əv fəɹ ðə lɔɹɾ ə fæl dæɹə hɪmsɛlf. ɛɛs sədaɪ, θɹi təɡɛðɝ, ən ði æmɪɝlɪn sit hɝsɛlf ɪn ðə kip; ɪt wɑz mɔɹ ɑnɝ ðən ɛni wʊmən ə ðə kip hæɾ ɛvɝ ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪn əɹ laɪftaɪm. ə fju wɪmən ə noʊbəl haʊsəz wɝ aʊɾ ɪn ðə hɔlz, ən ðeɪ kɝtsid, tu, wɪtʃ ðeɪ moʊst sɝɾənli wəd nɑɾ əv dʌn fəɹ lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ. mɔɪɹeɪn ən æneɪjə smaɪld ən baʊd ðɛɹ hɛdz tə æknɑlɪdʒ itʃ ɹɛvɝəns, fɹəm sɝvən əɹ noʊbəl ikwəli. liɑnʒɹɪn ɪɡnɔɹɾ əm ɔl.

Liveried women curtsied deeply as they passed, many more deeply than they would have for the Lord of Fal Dara himself. Aes Sedai, three together, and the Amyrlin Seat herself in the keep; it was more honor than any woman of the keep had ever expected in her lifetime. A few women of noble Houses were out in the halls, and they curtsied, too, which they most certainly would not have done for Lord Agelmar. Moiraine and Anaiya smiled and bowed their heads to acknowledge each reverence, from servant or noble equally. Liandrin ignored them all.

ðəɹ wɝ oʊnli wɪmən hɪɹ, ʌv kɔɹs, noʊ mɛn. noʊ ʃaɪnɝən meɪl əbʌv ði eɪdʒ ə tɛn wəɾ ɛntɝ ðə wɪmənz ɹumz wɪθaʊt pɝmɪʃən əɹ ɪnvɪteɪʃən, ɔlðoʊ ə fju smɔl bɔɪz ɹæn ən pleɪɾ ɪn ðə hɔlz hɪɹ. ðeɪ nɛlt ɑn wʌn ni, ɔkwɝdli, wən ðɛɹ sɪstɝz dʒɹɑp dip kɝtsiz. naʊ ən ðən æneɪjə smaɪld ən ɹʌfəld ə smɔl hɛɾ əz ʃi pæst.

There were only women here, of course, no men. No Shienaran male above the age of ten would enter the women's rooms without permission or invitation, although a few small boys ran and played in the halls here. They knelt on one knee, awkwardly, when their sisters dropped deep curtsies. Now and then Anaiya smiled and ruffled a small head as she passed.

"ðɪs taɪm, mɔɪɹeɪn," æneɪjə sɛd, "ju hæv bɪn ɡɔn fɹəm tɑɹ vəlɑn tu lɔŋ. mʌtʃ tu lɔŋ. tɑɹ vəlɑn mɪsəz ju. jəɹ sɪstɝz mɪs ju. ən jə ɑɹ niɾəd ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ."

"This time, Moiraine," Anaiya said, "you have been gone from Tar Valon too long. Much too long. Tar Valon misses you. Your sisters miss you. And you are needed in the White Tower."

"sʌm ʌv əs mʌst wɝk ɪn ðə wɝld," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd dʒɛnli. "aɪ wɪl liv ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ tə ju, æneɪjə. jɛɾ ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn, jə hɪɹ mɔɹ ʌv wʌɾ əkɝz ɪn ðə wɝl ðən aɪ. tu ɔfən aɪ aʊtʃɹʌn wʌt hæpənz wɛɹ aɪ wɑz jɛstɝdeɪ. wʌt nuz əv ju?"

"Some of us must work in the world," Moiraine said gently. "I will leave the Hall of the Tower to you, Anaiya. Yet in Tar Valon, you hear more of what occurs in the world than I. Too often I outrun what happens where I was yesterday. What news have you?"

"θɹi mɔɹ fɔls dʒɹæɡənz." liɑnʒɹɪn bɪt ðə wɝdz ɔf. "ɪn sɑldɑiə, mʊɹændi, ən tɛɹ fɔls dʒɹæɡənz ɹævədʒ ðə lænd. ðə waɪl, jə bluz smaɪl ən tɔk ə nʌθɪŋ, ən tʃɹaɪ tə hoʊld ɑn tə ðə pæst." æneɪjə ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ, ən liɑnʒɹɪn snæpt əɹ maʊθ ʃʌt wɪð ə ʃɑɹp snɪf.

"Three more false Dragons." Liandrin bit the words off. "In Saldaea, Murandy, and Tear false Dragons ravage the land. The while, you Blues smile and talk of nothing, and try to hold on to the past." Anaiya raised an eyebrow, and Liandrin snapped her mouth shut with a sharp sniff.

"θɹi," mɔɪɹeɪn mjuz sɔfli. fəɹ ən ɪnstən əɹ aɪz ɡlimd, bʌt ʃi mæskt ɪt kwɪkli. "θɹi ɪn ðə læs tu jɪɹz, ən naʊ θɹi mɔɹ ət wʌns."

"Three," Moiraine mused softly. For an instant her eyes gleamed, but she masked it quickly. "Three in the last two years, and now three more at once."

"æz ði ʌðɝz wɝ, ðiz wɪl bi dɛlt wɪð ɔlsoʊ. ðɪs meɪl vɝmɪn ən ɛni ɹæɡtæɡ ɹæbəl u fɑloʊ ðɛɹ bænɝz."

"As the others were, these will be dealt with also. This male vermin and any ragtag rabble who follow their banners."

mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz ɔlmoʊst əmjuz baɪ ðə sɝɾənti ɪn liɑnʒɹɪnz vɔɪs. ɔlmoʊst. ʃi wɑz tu əwɛɹ ə ðə ɹiæləɾiz, tu əwɛɹ ə ðə pɑsəbɪləɾiz. "hæv ə fju mʌnθs bɪn ɪnʌf fəɹ jə tə fɝɡɛt, sɪstɝ? ðə læs fɔls dʒɹæɡən ɔl bʌt tɔɹ ɡildən əpɑɹt bɪfɔɹ ɪz ɑɹmi, ɹæɡtæɡ ɹæbəl əɹ nɑt, wɑz dɪfiɾəd. jɛs, lɑɡən ɪz ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn baɪ naʊ, dʒɛntəld ən seɪf, aɪ səpoʊz, bʌt səm ʌv əɹ sɪstɝz daɪd tə oʊvɝpaʊɝ hɪm. ivən wʌn sɪstɝ dɛɾ ɪz mɔɹ lɔs ðən wi kən bɛɹ, bʌt ɡildənz lɔsəz wɝ mʌtʃ wɝs. ðə tu bɪfɔɹ lɑɡən kəd nɑt tʃænəl, jɛɾ ivən soʊ ðə pipəl ə kændɝ ən ɑɹæd dumən ɹɪmɛmbɝ əm wɛl. vɪlədʒəz bɝn ən mɛn dɛɾ ɪn bæɾəl. haʊ izəli kən ðə wɝl dil wɪð θɹi ət wʌn taɪm? haʊ mɛni wɪl flɑk tə ðɛɹ bænɝz? ðəɹ əz nɛvɝ bɪn ə ʃɔɹɾədʒ ə fɑloʊɝz fəɹ ɛni mæn kleɪmɪŋ tə bi ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. haʊ ɡɹeɪt wɪl ðə wɔɹz bi ðɪs taɪm?"

Moiraine was almost amused by the certainty in Liandrin's voice. Almost. She was too aware of the realities, too aware of the possibilities. "Have a few months been enough for you to forget, Sister? The last false Dragon all but tore Ghealdan apart before his army, ragtag rabble or not, was defeated. Yes, Logain is in Tar Valon by now, gentled and safe, I suppose, but some of our sisters died to overpower him. Even one sister dead is more loss than we can bear, but Ghealdan's losses were much worse. The two before Logain could not channel, yet even so the people of Kandor and Arad Doman remember them well. Villages burned and men dead in battle. How easily can the world deal with three at one time? How many will flock to their banners? There has never been a shortage of followers for any man claiming to be the Dragon Reborn. How great will the wars be this time?"

"ɪɾ ɪzən soʊ ɡɹɪm əz ðæt," æneɪjə sɛd. "æz fɑɹ əz wi noʊ, oʊnli ðə wʌn ɪn sɑldɑiə kən tʃænəl. hiz nɑt hæd taɪm tə ətʃɹæk mɛni fɑloʊɝz, ən sɪstɝz ʃəɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bi ðəɹ tə dil wɪð hɪm. ðə tɛɹənz ɑɹ hæɹiɪŋ ðɛɹ fɔls dʒɹæɡən ən ɪz fɑloʊɝz θɹu hæɾən mɝk, waɪl ðə fɛloʊ ɪn mʊɹændi ɪz ɔlɹɛɾi ɪn tʃeɪnz." ʃi ɡeɪv ə ʃɔɹt, wʌndɝɪŋ læf. "tə θɪŋk ðə mʊɹændiənz, ʌv ɔl pipəl, wəd dil wɪð ðɛɹz soʊ kwɪkli. æsk, ən ðeɪ də nɑɾ ivən kɔl ðɛmsɛlvz mʊɹændiənz, bʌt luɡɑɝɾɝz, əɹ ɪnɪʃlɪni, əɹ ðɪs əɹ ðət lɔɹdz əɹ leɪɾiz mæn. jɛt fəɹ fɪɹ wʌn ə ðɛɹ neɪbɝz wəd teɪk ði ɪkskjus tə ɪnveɪd, ðə mʊɹændiənz lɛpt ɑn ðɛɹ fɔls dʒɹæɡən ɔlmoʊst əz sun əz i oʊpən ɪz maʊθ tə pɹoʊkleɪm hɪmsɛlf."

"It isn't so grim as that," Anaiya said. "As far as we know, only the one in Saldaea can channel. He has not had time to attract many followers, and sisters should already be there to deal with him. The Tairens are harrying their false Dragon and his followers through Haddon Mirk, while the fellow in Murandy is already in chains." She gave a short, wondering laugh. "To think the Murandians, of all people, would deal with theirs so quickly. Ask, and they do not even call themselves Murandians, but Lugarders, or Inishlinni, or this or that lord's or lady's man. Yet for fear one of their neighbors would take the excuse to invade, the Murandians leaped on their false Dragon almost as soon as he opened his mouth to proclaim himself."

"stɪl," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, "θɹi ət ðə seɪm taɪm kænɑt bi ɪɡnɔɹd. hæz ɛni sɪstɝ bɪn eɪbəl tə də ə fɔɹtɛlɪŋ?" ɪt wɑz ə slaɪt tʃæns - fju ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd mænəfɛstəɾ ɛni pɑɹɾ ə ðət tælənt, ivən ðə smɔləs pɑɹt, ɪn sɛntʃɝiz - soʊ ʃi wɑz nɑt sɝpɹaɪzd wən æneɪjə ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. nɑt sɝpɹaɪzd, bʌɾ ə lɪɾəl ɹɪlivd.

"Still," Moiraine said, "three at the same time cannot be ignored. Has any sister been able to do a Foretelling?" It was a slight chance - few Aes Sedai had manifested any part of that Talent, even the smallest part, in centuries - so she was not surprised when Anaiya shook her head. Not surprised, but a little relieved.

ðeɪ ɹitʃt ə dʒʌŋktʃɝ ə hɔlweɪz ət ðə seɪm taɪm əz ðə leɪɾi əmælisə. ʃi dʒɹɑpt ə fʊl kɝtsi, boʊɪŋ dip ən spɹɛɾɪŋ əɹ peɪl ɡɹin skɝts waɪd. "ɑnɝ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn," ʃi mɝmɝd. "ɑnɝ tə ɛɛs sədaɪ."

They reached a juncture of hallways at the same time as the Lady Amalisa. She dropped a full curtsy, bowing deep and spreading her pale green skirts wide. "Honor to Tar Valon," she murmured. "Honor to Aes Sedai."

ðə sɪstɝ ə ðə lɔɹɾ ə fæl dæɹə ɹikwaɪɝd mɔɹ ðən ə nɑɾ ə ðə hɛd. mɔɪɹeɪn tʊk əmælisəz hænz ən dʒɹu hɝ tə hɝ fit. "ju ɑnɝ ʌs, əmælisə. ɹaɪz, sɪstɝ."

The sister of the Lord of Fal Dara required more than a nod of the head. Moiraine took Amalisa's hands and drew her to her feet. "You honor us, Amalisa. Rise, Sister."

əmælisə stʃɹeɪɾɪd ɡɹeɪsfəli, wɪð ə flʌʃ ɑn əɹ feɪs. ʃi hæd nɛvɝ əz mʌtʃ əz bɪn tə tɑɹ vəlɑn, ən tə bi kɔl sɪstɝ baɪ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑz hɛɾi ivən fəɹ sʌmwʌn ə hɝ ɹæŋk. ʃɔɹɾ ən ə mɪɾəl jɪɹz, ʃi hæɾ ə dɑɹk, mətʃʊɹ bjuɾi, ən ðə kʌlɝ ɪn əɹ tʃiks sɛɾ ɪɾ ɔf. "ju ɑnɝ mi tu ɡɹeɪtli, mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ."

Amalisa straighted gracefully, with a flush on her face. She had never as much as been to Tar Valon, and to be called Sister by an Aes Sedai was heady even for someone of her rank. Short and of middle years, she had a dark, mature beauty, and the color in her cheeks set it off. "You honor me too greatly, Moiraine Sedai."

mɔɪɹeɪn smaɪld. "haʊ lɔŋ əv wi noʊn itʃ ʌðɝ, əmælisə? mʌst aɪ naʊ kɔl jə maɪ leɪɾi əmælisə, əz ɪf wi hæd nɛvɝ sæɾ oʊvɝ ti təɡɛðɝ?"

Moiraine smiled. "How long have we known each other, Amalisa? Must I now call you my Lady Amalisa, as if we had never sat over tea together?"

"ʌv kɔɹs nɑt." əmælisə smaɪl bæk. ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ ɛvəɾənt ɪn əɹ bɹʌðɝz feɪs wɑz ɪn hɝz, tu, ən noʊ lɛs fəɹ ðə sɑftɝ laɪn ə tʃik ən dʒɔ. ðəɹ wɝ ðoʊz u sɛd ðəɾ əz hɑɹɾ ən ɹɪnaʊn ə faɪɾɝ əz eɪɡəlmɝ wɑz, hi wɑz noʊ bɛɾɝ ðən ən ivən mætʃ fəɹ ɪz sɪstɝ. "bʌt wɪð ði æmɪɝlɪn sit hɪɹ. . . . wən kɪŋ isɑɹ vɪzəts fæl dæɹə, ɪn pɹaɪvəɾ aɪ kɔl ɪm mæɡɑmi, lɪɾəl ʌŋkəl, əz aɪ dɪd wən aɪ wɑz ə tʃaɪld ən i ɡeɪv mi ɹaɪdz ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, bʌɾ ɪn pʌblɪk ɪt mʌs bi dɪfɹənt."

"Of course not." Amalisa smiled back. The strength evident in her brother's face was in hers, too, and no less for the softer line of cheek and jaw. There were those who said that as hard and renowned a fighter as Agelmar was, he was no better than an even match for his sister. "But with the Amyrlin Seat here. . . . When King Easar visits Fal Dara, in private I call him Magami, Little Uncle, as I did when I was a child and he gave me rides on his shoulder, but in public it must be different."

æneɪjə tskt. "səmtaɪmz fɔɹmæləɾi ɪz nɛsəsɛɹi, bʌt mɛn ɔfən meɪk mɔɹ ʌv ɪt ðən ðeɪ mʌst. pliz, kɔl mi æneɪjə, ən əl kɔl jə əmælisə, ɪf aɪ meɪ."

Anaiya tsked. "Sometimes formality is necessary, but men often make more of it than they must. Please, call me Anaiya, and I will call you Amalisa, if I may."

fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɝ aɪ, mɔɪɹeɪn sɔ ɛɡwin, fɑɹ daʊn ðə saɪd hɔl, dɪsəpɪɹɪŋ hɝidli ɝaʊn ə kɔɹnɝ. ə stupt ʃeɪp ɪn ə lɛðɝ dʒɝkɪn, hɛd daʊn ən ɑɹmz loʊɾəd wɪð bʌndəlz, ʃæmbəld əɾ əɹ hilz. mɔɪɹeɪn pɝmɪɾəd hɝsɛlf ə smɔl smaɪl, kwɪkli mæskt. ɪf ðə ɡɝl ʃoʊz əz mʌtʃ ɪnɪʃəɾɪv ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn, ʃi θɔt ɹaɪli, ʃɪl sɪɾ ɪn ði æmɪɝlɪn sit wʌn deɪ. ɪf ʃi kən lɝn tə kəntʃɹoʊl ðəɾ ɪnɪʃəɾɪv. ɪf ðəɹ ɪz ən æmɪɝlɪn sit lɛft ɑn wɪtʃ tə sɪt.

From the corner of her eye, Moiraine saw Egwene, far down the side hall, disappearing hurriedly around a corner. A stooped shape in a leather jerkin, head down and arms loaded with bundles, shambled at her heels. Moiraine permitted herself a small smile, quickly masked. If the girl shows as much initiative in Tar Valon, she thought wryly, she will sit in the Amyrlin Seat one day. If she can learn to control that initiative. If there is an Amyrlin Seat left on which to sit.

wən ʃi tɝn əɹ ətɛnʃən bæk tə ði ʌðɝz, liɑnʒɹɪn wɑz spikɪŋ.

When she turned her attention back to the others, Liandrin was speaking.

". . . ən aɪ wəd wɛlkəm ðə tʃæns tə lɝn mɔɹ ə jəɹ lænd." ʃi wɔɹ ə smaɪl, oʊpən ən ɔlmoʊst ɡɝlɪʃ, ən əɹ vɔɪs wɑz fɹɛnli.

". . . and I would welcome the chance to learn more of your land." She wore a smile, open and almost girlish, and her voice was friendly.

mɔɪɹeɪn skuld əɹ feɪs tə stɪlnəs əz əmælisə ɪkstɛndəɾ ən ɪnvɪteɪʃən tə dʒɔɪn əɹ ən əɹ leɪɾiz ɪn əɹ pɹaɪvət ɡɑɹɾən, ən liɑnʒɹɪn æksɛptɪd wɔɹmli. liɑnʒɹɪn meɪd fju fɹɛnz, ən nʌn aʊtsaɪd ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ. sɝɾənli nɛvɝ aʊtsaɪd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ʃi wəd sunɝ meɪk fɹɛnz wɪð ə mæn, əɹ ə tʃɹɑlɑk. mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ liɑnʒɹɪn sɔ mʌtʃ dɪfɝəns bɪtwin mɛn ən tʃɹɑləks. ʃi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ɛni ʌv ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ dɪd.

Moiraine schooled her face to stillness as Amalisa extended an invitation to join her and her ladies in her private garden, and Liandrin accepted warmly. Liandrin made few friends, and none outside the Red Ajah. Certainly never outside the Aes Sedai. She would sooner make friends with a man, or a Trolloc. Moiraine was not sure Liandrin saw much difference between men and Trollocs. She was not sure any of the Red Ajah did.

æneɪjə ɪkspleɪn ðət dʒʌs naʊ ðeɪ mʌst ətɛn ði æmɪɝlɪn sit. "ʌv kɔɹs," əmælisə sɛd. "ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin hɝ, ən ðə kɹieɪɾɝ ʃɛltɝ hɝ. bʌt leɪɾɝ, ðɛn." ʃi stʊd stʃɹeɪɾ ən baʊɾ əɹ hɛɾ əz ðeɪ lɛf hɝ.

Anaiya explained that just now they must attend the Amyrlin Seat. "Of course," Amalisa said. "The Light illumine her, and the Creator shelter her. But later, then." She stood straight and bowed her head as they left her.

mɔɪɹeɪn stʌɾid liɑnʒɹɪn əz ðeɪ wɔkt, nɛvɝ lʊkɪŋ əɾ əɹ dɝɛkli. ðə hʌni-hɛɹɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑz stɛɹɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛd, ɹoʊzbʌd lɪps pɝs θɔtfəli. ʃi əpɪɹd tə hæv fɝɡɑɾən mɔɪɹeɪn ən æneɪjə boʊθ. wʌɾ ɪz ʃi ʌp tə?

Moiraine studied Liandrin as they walked, never looking at her directly. The honey-haired Aes Sedai was staring straight ahead, rosebud lips pursed thoughtfully. She appeared to have forgotten Moiraine and Anaiya both. What is she up to?

æneɪjə sim nɑt tə hæv noʊɾəst ɛniθɪŋ aʊɾ ə ði ɔɹɾənɛɹi, bʌt ðən ʃi ɔlweɪz mænədʒ tə æksɛpt pipəl boʊθ əz ðeɪ wɝ ən əz ðeɪ wɑntəd tə bi. ɪt kɑnstənli əmeɪz mɔɪɹeɪn ðəɾ æneɪjə dɛlt əz wɛl əz ʃi dɪɾ ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, bʌt ðoʊz u wɝ diviəs ɔlweɪz sim tə teɪk əɹ oʊpənnəs ən ɑnəsti, hɝ æksɛptəns ʌv ɛvɹiwʌn, əz kʌnɪŋ dɪvaɪsəz. ðeɪ wɝ ɔlweɪz kɑt kəmplitli ɔf bæləns wən ʃi tɝn aʊt tə min wʌt ʃi sɛɾ ən seɪ wʌt ʃi mɛnt. tu, ʃi hæɾ ə weɪ ʌv siɪŋ tə ðə hɑɹɾ ə θɪŋz. ən ʌv æksɛptɪŋ wʌt ʃi sɔ. naʊ ʃi blaɪθli ɹɪzum spikɪŋ ə ðə nuz.

Anaiya seemed not to have noticed anything out of the ordinary, but then she always managed to accept people both as they were and as they wanted to be. It constantly amazed Moiraine that Anaiya dealt as well as she did in the White Tower, but those who were devious always seemed to take her openness and honesty, her acceptance of everyone, as cunning devices. They were always caught completely off balance when she turned out to mean what she said and say what she meant. Too, she had a way of seeing to the heart of things. And of accepting what she saw. Now she blithely resumed speaking of the news.

"ðə wɝd fɹəm ændɝ ɪz boʊθ ɡʊɾ ən bæd. ðə stʃɹit ɹaɪəts ɪn keɪɛmlɪn daɪd daʊn wɪð ðə kʌmɪŋ ə spɹɪŋ, bʌt ðəɹ ɪz stɪl tɔk, tu mʌtʃ tɔk, bleɪmɪŋ ðə kwin, ən tɑɹ vəlɑn əz wɛl, fəɹ ðə lɔŋ wɪntɝ. mɔɹɡeɪs hoʊlz əɹ θɹoʊn lɛs sɪkjʊɹli ðən ʃi dɪd læs jɪɹ, bʌt ʃi hoʊlz ɪt stɪl, ən wɪl soʊ lɔŋ əz ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn ɪz kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl ə ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz. ən ðə leɪɾi ɪleɪn, ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ, ən əɹ bɹʌðɝ, ðə lɔɹd ɡɔɪn, hæv kʌm seɪfli tə tɑɹ vəlɑn fəɹ ðɛɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ. ðəɹ wɑz səm fɪɹ ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ ðət ðə kʌstəm wəd bi bɹoʊkən."

"The word from Andor is both good and bad. The street riots in Caemlyn died down with the coming of spring, but there is still talk, too much talk, blaming the Queen, and Tar Valon as well, for the long winter. Morgase holds her throne less securely than she did last year, but she holds it still, and will so long as Gareth Bryne is Captain-General of the Queen's Guards. And the Lady Elayne, the Daughter-Heir, and her brother, the Lord Gawyn, have come safely to Tar Valon for their training. There was some fear in the White Tower that the custom would be broken."

"nɑt waɪl mɔɹɡeɪs əz bɹɛθ ɪn əɹ bɑɾi," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd.

"Not while Morgase has breath in her body," Moiraine said.

liɑnʒɹɪn ɡeɪv ə lɪɾəl stɑɹt, əz ɪf ʃi hæd dʒʌst əweɪkənd. "pɹeɪ ðət ʃi kəntɪnjuz tə hæv bɹɛθ. ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹz pɑɹɾi wɑz fɑloʊd tə ðə ɹɪvɝ ɛɹɪnɪn baɪ ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt. tə ðə vɛɹi bɹɪdʒəz tə tɑɹ vəlɑn. mɔɹ stɪl kæmp aʊtsaɪd keɪɛmlɪn, fəɹ ðə tʃæns ə mɪstʃəf, ən ɪnsaɪd keɪɛmlɪn stɪl ɑɹ ðoʊz u lɪsən."

Liandrin gave a little start, as if she had just awakened. "Pray that she continues to have breath. The Daughter-Heir's party was followed to the River Erinin by the Children of the Light. To the very bridges to Tar Valon. More still camp outside Caemlyn, for the chance of mischief, and inside Caemlyn still are those who listen."

"pɝhæps ɪts taɪm mɔɹɡeɪs lɝn ə lɪɾəl kɑʃən," æneɪjə saɪd. "ðə wɝld ɪz bɪkʌmɪŋ mɔɹ deɪnʒɝəs ɛvɹi deɪ, ivən fəɹ ə kwin. pɝhæps ɪspɛʃli fəɹ ə kwin. ʃi wɑz ɛvɝ hɛdstʃɹɔŋ. aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ wən ʃi keɪm tə tɑɹ vəlɑn əz ə ɡɝl. ʃi dɪd nɑɾ əv ði əbɪləɾi tə bɪkʌm ə fʊl sɪstɝ, ən ɪt ɹæŋkəld ɪn hɝ. səmtaɪmz aɪ θɪŋk ʃi pʊʃəz əɹ dɔɾɝ kəz ə ðæt, wʌtɛvɝ ðə ɡɝl tʃuzəz."

"Perhaps it is time Morgase learned a little caution," Anaiya sighed. "The world is becoming more dangerous every day, even for a queen. Perhaps especially for a queen. She was ever headstrong. I remember when she came to Tar Valon as a girl. She did not have the ability to become a full sister, and it rankled in her. Sometimes I think she pushes her daughter because of that, whatever the girl chooses."

mɔɪɹeɪn snɪf dɪsdeɪnfəli. "ɪleɪn wɑz bɔɹn wɪð ðə spɑɹk ɪn hɝ; ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə mæɾɝ ə tʃuzɪŋ. mɔɹɡeɪs wəd nɑt ɹɪsk lɛɾɪŋ ðə ɡɝl daɪ fɹəm læk ə tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ɪf ɔl ðə waɪtkloʊks ɪn ɑmɑdɪʃiə wɝ kæmpt aʊtsaɪd keɪɛmlɪn. ʃi wəd kəmænd ɡɛɹɪθ bɝn ən ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz tə kʌɾ ə pæθ θɹu ðɛm tə tɑɹ vəlɑn, ən ɡɛɹɪθ bɝn wəd də ɪɾ ɪf i hæd tə də ɪɾ əloʊn." bʌt ʃi stɪl mʌs kip ðə fʊl ɪkstɛn ə ðə ɡɝlz pətɛnʃəl sikɹət. wəd ðə pipəl ʌv ændɝ noʊɪŋli æksɛpt ɪleɪn ɑn ðə laɪən θɹoʊn æftɝ mɔɹɡeɪs ɪf ðeɪ nu? nɑt dʒʌst ə kwin tʃɹeɪn ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə kʌstəm, bʌɾ ə fʊl ɛɛs sədaɪ? ɪn ɔl ə ɹəkɔɹɾəd hɪstɝi ðəɹ hæd bɪn oʊnli ə hændfʊl ə kwinz wɪð ðə ɹaɪt tə bi kɔld ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən ðə fju hu lɛɾ ɪt bi noʊn hæɾ ɔl lɪv tə ɹəɡɹɛɾ ɪt. ʃi fɛlt ə tʌtʃ ə sædnəs. bʌt tu mʌtʃ wɑz əfʊt tə spɛɹ eɪd, əɹ ivən wɝi, fəɹ wʌn læn ən wʌn θɹoʊn. "wʌɾ ɛls, æneɪjə?"

Moiraine sniffed disdainfully. "Elayne was born with the spark in her; it was not a matter of choosing. Morgase would not risk letting the girl die from lack of training if all the Whitecloaks in Amadicia were camped outside Caemlyn. She would command Gareth Byrne and the Queen's Guards to cut a path through them to Tar Valon, and Gareth Byrne would do it if he had to do it alone." But she still must keep the full extent of the girl's potential secret. Would the people of Andor knowingly accept Elayne on the Lion Throne after Morgase if they knew? Not just a queen trained in Tar Valon according to custom, but a full Aes Sedai? In all of recorded history there had been only a handful of queens with the right to be called Aes Sedai, and the few who let it be known had all lived to regret it. She felt a touch of sadness. But too much was afoot to spare aid, or even worry, for one land and one throne. "What else, Anaiya?"

"ju mʌs noʊ ðət ðə ɡɹeɪt hʌn ə ðə hɔɹn əz bɪn kɔld ɪn ɪljən, ðə fɝs taɪm ɪn fɔɹ hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz. ði ɪliɑnɝz seɪ ðə læs bæɾəl ɪz kʌmɪŋ" - æneɪjə ɡeɪv ə lɪɾəl ʃɪvɝ, əz wɛl ʃi maɪt, bʌt wɛn ɑn wɪθaʊɾ ə pɔz - "æn ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ mʌs bi faʊn bɪfɔɹ ðə faɪnəl bæɾəl əɡɛns ðə ʃædoʊ. mɛn fɹəm ɛvɹi læn ɑɹ ɔlɹɛɾi ɡæðɝɪŋ, ɔl iɡɝ tə bi pɑɹɾ ə ðə lɛdʒənd, iɡɝ tə faɪn ðə hɔɹn. mʊɹændi ən ɔltɑɹə ɑɹ ɑn ðɛɹ toʊz, ʌv kɔɹs, θɪŋkɪŋ ɪts ɔl ə mæsk fəɹ ə muv əɡɛnst wʌn ə ðɛm. ðəɾ ɪz pɹɑbli waɪ ðə mʊɹændiənz kɑt ðɛɹ fɔls dʒɹæɡən soʊ kwɪkli. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ðəɹ wɪl bi ə nu lɑɾ ə stɔɹiz fəɹ ðə bɑɹdz ən ɡlimən tə æd tə ðə saɪkəl. ðə laɪt sɛn ɪts oʊnli nu stɔɹiz."

"You must know that the Great Hunt of the Horn has been called in Illian, the first time in four hundred years. The Illianers say the Last Battle is coming" - Anaiya gave a little shiver, as well she might, but went on without a pause - "and the Horn of Valere must be found before the final battle against the Shadow. Men from every land are already gathering, all eager to be part of the legend, eager to find the Horn. Murandy and Altara are on their toes, of course, thinking it's all a mask for a move against one of them. That is probably why the Murandians caught their false Dragon so quickly. In any case, there will be a new lot of stories for the bards and gleemen to add to the cycle. The Light send it is only new stories."

"pɝhæps nɑt ðə stɔɹiz ðeɪ ɪkspɛkt," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. liɑnʒɹɪn lʊkt əɾ əɹ ʃɑɹpli, ən ʃi kɛpt əɹ feɪs stɪl.

"Perhaps not the stories they expect," Moiraine said. Liandrin looked at her sharply, and she kept her face still.

"aɪ səpoʊz nɑt," æneɪjə sɛd plɑtʃədli. "ðə stɔɹiz ðeɪ list ɪkspɛkt wɪl bi ɪɡzækli ðə wʌnz ðəl æd tə ðə saɪkəl. bɪɑn ðæt, aɪ hæv oʊnli ɹumɝ tə ɔfɝ. ðə si foʊk ɑɹ ædʒəteɪɾəd, ðɛɹ ʃɪps flaɪɪŋ fɹəm pɔɹt tə pɔɹt wɪð bɛɹli ə pɔz. sɪstɝz fɹəm ði aɪlənz seɪ ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ, ðɛɹ tʃoʊzən wʌn, ɪz kʌmɪŋ, bʌt ðeɪ woʊn seɪ mɔɹ. jə noʊ haʊ kloʊs-maʊðd ði æθɑn maɪɹ ɑɹ wɪð aʊtsaɪɾɝz əbaʊt ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ, ən ɪn ðɪs əɹ sɪstɝz sim tə θɪŋk mɔɹ əz si foʊk ðən ɛɛs sədaɪ. ði il əpɪɹ tə bi stɝɪŋ, tu, bʌt noʊ wʌn noʊz waɪ. noʊ wʌn ɛvɝ noʊz wɪð ði il. ət lis ðəɹ ɪz noʊ ɛvəɾəns ðeɪ min tə kɹɔs ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝld əɡɛn, θæŋk ðə laɪt." ʃi saɪɾ ən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "wʌɾ aɪ wəd nɑt ɡɪv fəɹ ivən wʌn sɪstɝ fɹəm əmʌŋ ði il. dʒʌst wʌn. wi noʊ tu lɪɾəl ə ðɛm."

"I suppose not," Anaiya said placidly. "The stories they least expect will be exactly the ones they will add to the cycle. Beyond that, I have only rumor to offer. The Sea Folk are agitated, their ships flying from port to port with barely a pause. Sisters from the islands say the Coramoor, their Chosen One, is coming, but they won't say more. You know how close-mouthed the Atha'an Miere are with outsiders about the Coramoor, and in this our sisters seem to think more as Sea Folk than Aes Sedai. The Aiel appear to be stirring, too, but no one knows why. No one ever knows with the Aiel. At least there is no evidence they mean to cross the Spine of the World again, thank the Light." She sighed and shook her head. "What I would not give for even one sister from among the Aiel. Just one. We know too little of them."

mɔɪɹeɪn læft. "səmtaɪmz aɪ θɪŋk jə bɪlɔŋ ɪn ðə bɹaʊn ədʒɑ, æneɪjə."

Moiraine laughed. "Sometimes I think you belong in the Brown Ajah, Anaiya."

"ɑlməθ pleɪn," liɑnʒɹɪn sɛd, ən lʊk sɝpɹaɪz ðət ʃi hæd spoʊkən.

"Almoth Plain," Liandrin said, and looked surprised that she had spoken.

"naʊ ðət tʃɹuli ɪz ɹumɝ, sɪstɝ," æneɪjə sɛd. "ə fju wɪspɝz hɝɾ əz wi wɝ livɪŋ tɑɹ vəlɑn. ðəɹ meɪ bi faɪɾɪŋ ɑn ɑlməθ pleɪn, ən pɝhæps toʊmən hɛd, əz wɛl. aɪ seɪ, meɪ bi. ðə wɪspɝz wɝ feɪnt. ɹumɝz ə ɹumɝz. wi lɛf bɪfɔɹ wi kəd hɪɹ mɔɹ."

"Now that truly is rumor, Sister," Anaiya said. "A few whispers heard as we were leaving Tar Valon. There may be fighting on Almoth Plain, and perhaps Toman Head, as well. I say, may be. The whispers were faint. Rumors of rumors. We left before we could hear more."

"ɪt wəɾ əv tə bi tæɹɑbən ən ɑɹæd dumən," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, ən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "ðeɪ hæv skwɑbəld oʊvɝ ɑlməθ pleɪn fəɹ nɪɹli θɹi hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz, bʌɾ ɪts nɛvɝ kʌm tə oʊpən bloʊz." ʃi lʊkt ət liɑnʒɹɪn; ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ səpoʊz tə θɹoʊ ɔf ɔl ðɛɹ oʊld lɔɪəltiz tə lænz ən ɹulɝz, bʌt fju dɪd soʊ kəmplitli. ɪt wɑz hɑɹd nɑt tə kɛɹ fəɹ ðə læn ə jəɹ bɝθ. "waɪ wəd ðeɪ naʊ - ?"

"It would have to be Tarabon and Arad Doman," Moiraine said, and shook her head. "They have squabbled over Almoth Plain for nearly three hundred years, but it has never come to open blows." She looked at Liandrin; Aes Sedai were supposed to throw off all their old loyalties to lands and rulers, but few did so completely. It was hard not to care for the land of your birth. "Why would they now - ?"

"ɪnʌf ʌv aɪɾəl tɔk," ðə hʌni-hɛɹd wʊmən bɹoʊk ɪn æŋɡɹəli. "fɔɹ ju, mɔɪɹeɪn, ði æmɪɝlɪn weɪts." ʃi tʊk θɹi kwɪk stʃɹaɪdz əhɛɾ ə ði ʌðɝz ən θɹu oʊpən wʌn ʌv ə pɛɹ ə tɔl dɔɹz. "fɔɹ ju, ði æmɪɝlɪn wɪl əv noʊ aɪɾəl tɔk."

"Enough of idle talk," the honey-haired woman broke in angrily. "For you, Moiraine, the Amyrlin waits." She took three quick strides ahead of the others and threw open one of a pair of tall doors. "For you, the Amyrlin will have no idle talk."

ʌnkɑnʃəsli tʌtʃɪŋ ðə paʊtʃ əɾ əɹ weɪst, mɔɪɹeɪn wɛn pæs liɑnʒɹɪn θɹu ðə dɔɹweɪ, wɪð ə nɑɾ əz ɪf ði ʌðɝ wʊmən wɝ hoʊldɪŋ ðə dɔɹ fəɹ hɝ. ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ivən smaɪl ət ðə waɪt flæʃ ʌv æŋɡɝ ɑn liɑnʒɹɪnz feɪs. wʌɾ ɪz ðə ɹɛtʃɪd ɡɝl ʌp tə?

Unconsciously touching the pouch at her waist, Moiraine went past Liandrin through the doorway, with a nod as if the other woman were holding the door for her. She did not even smile at the white flash of anger on Liandrin's face. What is the wretched girl up to?

bɹaɪtli kʌlɝd kɑɹpəts kʌvɝd ði æntəɹum flɔɹ ɪn leɪɝz, ən ðə ɹum wɑz plɛzənli fɝnɪʃt wɪð tʃɛɹz ən kʊʃən bɛntʃɪz ən smɔl teɪbəlz, ðə wʊd sɪmpli wɝkt əɹ dʒʌs pɑlɪʃt. bɹoʊkeɪɾɪd kɝɾənz saɪɾəd ðə tɔl æɹoʊslɪts tə meɪk əm sim mɔɹ laɪk wɪndoʊz. noʊ faɪɝz bɝn ɪn ðə faɪɝpleɪsəz; ðə deɪ wɑz wɔɹm, ən ðə ʃaɪnɝən tʃɪl wəd nɑt kʌm əntɪl naɪtfɔl.

Brightly colored carpets covered the anteroom floor in layers, and the room was pleasantly furnished with chairs and cushioned benches and small tables, the wood simply worked or just polished. Brocaded curtains sided the tall arrowslits to make them seem more like windows. No fires burned in the fireplaces; the day was warm, and the Shienaran chill would not come until nightfall.

fjuɝ ðən hæf ə dʌzən ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hu hæɾ əkʌmpənid ði æmɪɝlɪn wɝ ðɛɹ. vɛɹɪn mæθwɪn ən sɹəfɛl, ʌv ðə bɹaʊn ədʒɑ, dɪd nɑt lʊk ʌp ət mɔɪɹeɪnz ɛntʃɹəns. sɹəfɛl wɑz ɪntɛnli ɹiɾɪŋ ən oʊl bʊk wɪð ə wɔɹn, feɪɾəd lɛðɝ kʌvɝ, hænlɪŋ ɪts tæɾɝd peɪdʒəz kɛɹfəli, waɪl plʌmp vɛɹɪn, sɪɾɪŋ kɹɔs-lɛɡəd bɪniθ ən æɹoʊslɪt, hɛld ə smɔl blɑsəm ʌp tə ðə laɪɾ ən meɪd noʊts ən skɛtʃəz ɪn ə pɹɪsaɪs hæn ɪn ə bʊk bælənst ɑn əɹ ni. ʃi hæɾ ən oʊpən ɪŋkpɑɾ ɑn ðə flɔɹ bɪsaɪd hɝ, ən ə smɔl paɪl ə flaʊɝz ɑn əɹ læp. ðə bɹaʊn sɪstɝz kənsɝn ðɛmsɛlvz wɪð lɪɾəl bɪsaɪd sikɪŋ nɑlədʒ. mɔɪɹeɪn səmtaɪmz wʌndɝɾ ɪf ðeɪ wɝ ɹɪli əwɛɹ ʌv wʌt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn ɪn ðə wɝld, əɹ ivən ɪmiɾiətli ɝaʊn ðɛm.

Fewer than half a dozen of the Aes Sedai who had accompanied the Amyrlin were there. Verin Mathwin and Serafelle, of the Brown Ajah, did not look up at Moiraine's entrance. Serafelle was intently reading an old book with a worn, faded leather cover, handling its tattered pages carefully, while plump Verin, sitting cross-legged beneath an arrowslit, held a small blossom up to the light and made notes and sketches in a precise hand in a book balanced on her knee. She had an open inkpot on the floor beside her, and a small pile of flowers on her lap. The Brown sisters concerned themselves with little beside seeking knowledge. Moiraine sometimes wondered if they were really aware of what was going on in the world, or even immediately around them.

ðə θɹi ʌðɝ wɪmən ɔlɹɛɾi ɪn ðə ɹum tɝnd, bʌt ðeɪ meɪd noʊ ɛfɝt tə əpɹoʊtʃ mɔɪɹeɪn, oʊnli lʊkt ət hɝ. wʌn, ə slɛndɝ wʊmən ə ðə jɛloʊ ədʒɑ, ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ; ʃi spɛn tu lɪɾəl taɪm ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn tə noʊ ɔl ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɔlðoʊ ðɛɹ nʌmbɝz wɝ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ vɛɹi ɡɹeɪt. ʃi wɑz əkweɪntəd wɪð ðə tu ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ, haʊɛvɝ. kɑɹlɪnjə wɑz əz peɪl ə skɪn ən koʊld ə mænɝ əz ðə waɪt fɹɪnʒ ɑn əɹ ʃɔl, ði ɪɡzækt ɑpəzəɾ ɪn ɛvɹi weɪ ʌv dɑɹk, faɪɝi ɑlɑnə mɑsvɑni, ʌv ðə ɡɹin, bʌt ðeɪ boʊθ stʊɾ ən stɛɹɾ əɾ əɹ wɪθaʊt spikɪŋ, wɪθaʊɾ ɪkspɹɛʃən. ɑlɑnə ʃɑɹpli snʌɡd əɹ ʃɔl ɝaʊn hɝ, bʌt kɑɹlɪnjə meɪd noʊ muv əɾ ɔl. ðə slɛndɝ jɛloʊ sɪstɝ tɝn əweɪ wɪð ən ɛɹ ə ɹəɡɹɛt.

The three other women already in the room turned, but they made no effort to approach Moiraine, only looked at her. One, a slender woman of the Yellow Ajah, she did not know; she spent too little time in Tar Valon to know all the Aes Sedai, although their numbers were no longer very great. She was acquainted with the two remaining, however. Carlinya was as pale of skin and cold of manner as the white fringe on her shawl, the exact opposite in every way of dark, fiery Alanna Mosvani, of the Green, but they both stood and stared at her without speaking, without expression. Alanna sharply snugged her shawl around her, but Carlinya made no move at all. The slender Yellow sister turned away with an air of regret.

"ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin jə ɔl, sɪstɝz," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. noʊ wʌn ænsɝd. ʃi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ sɹəfɛl əɹ vɛɹɪn hæɾ ivən hɝd. wɛɹ ɑɹ ði ʌðɝz? ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid fəɹ əm ɔl tə bi ðəɹ - moʊst wəd bi ɹɛstɪŋ ɪn ðɛɹ ɹumz, fɹɛʃɪŋ fɹəm ðə dʒɝni - bʌt ʃi wɑz ɑn ɛdʒ naʊ, ɔl ðə kwɛstʃənz ʃi kəd nɑɾ æsk ɹʌnɪŋ θɹu hɝ hɛd. nʌn ʌv ɪt ʃoʊɾ ɑn əɹ feɪs.

"The Light illumine you all, Sisters," Moiraine said. No one answered. She was not sure Serafelle or Verin had even heard. Where are the others? There was no need for them all to be there - most would be resting in their rooms, freshing from the journey - but she was on edge now, all the questions she could not ask running through her head. None of it showed on her face.

ði ɪnɝ dɔɹ oʊpənd, ən lin əpɪɹd, wɪθaʊɾ əɹ ɡɪlt-fleɪm stæf. ðə kipɝ ə ðə kɹɑnəkəlz wɑz əz tɔl əz moʊs mɛn, wɪləwi ən ɡɹeɪsfəl, stɪl bjuɾəfəl, wɪð kɑpɝi skɪn ən ʃɔɹt, dɑɹk hɛɹ. ʃi wɔɹ ə blu stoʊl, ə hænd waɪd, ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ə ʃɔl, fəɹ ʃi sæɾ ɪn ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ, ðoʊ əz kipɝ, nɑt tə ɹɛpɹəzɛn əɹ ədʒɑ.

The inner door opened, and Leane appeared, without her gilt-flamed staff. The Keeper of the Chronicles was as tall as most men, willowy and graceful, still beautiful, with coppery skin and short, dark hair. She wore a blue stole, a hand wide, instead of a shawl, for she sat in the Hall of the Tower, though as Keeper, not to represent her Ajah.

"ðɛɹ jə ɑɹ," ʃi sɛd bɹɪskli tə mɔɪɹeɪn, ən dʒɛstʃɝd tə ðə dɔɹ bɪhaɪn hɝ. "kʌm, sɪstɝ. ði æmɪɝlɪn siɾ ɪz weɪɾɪŋ." ʃi spoʊk nætʃɹəli ɪn ə klɪpt, kwɪk weɪ ðət nɛvɝ tʃeɪnʒd, wɛðɝ ʃi wɑz æŋɡɹi əɹ dʒɔɪfəl əɹ ɪksaɪɾəd. əz mɔɪɹeɪn fɑloʊd lin ɪn, ʃi wʌndɝd wʌɾ ɪmoʊʃən ðə kipɝ wɑz filɪŋ naʊ. lin pʊl ðə dɔɹ tə bɪhaɪn ðɛm; ɪt bæŋd ʃʌt wɪð sʌmθɪŋ ə ðə saʊn ʌv ə sɛl dɔɹ kloʊzɪŋ.

"There you are," she said briskly to Moiraine, and gestured to the door behind her. "Come, Sister. The Amyrlin Seat is waiting." She spoke naturally in a clipped, quick way that never changed, whether she was angry or joyful or excited. As Moiraine followed Leane in, she wondered what emotion the Keeper was feeling now. Leane pulled the door to behind them; it banged shut with something of the sound of a cell door closing.

ði æmɪɝlɪn sit hɝsɛlf sæt bɪhaɪn ə bɹɔd teɪbəl ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə kɑɹpət, ən ɑn ðə teɪbəl ɹɛstəɾ ə flæɾənd kjub ʌv ɡoʊld, ðə saɪz ʌv ə tʃɹævəl tʃɛst ən ɔɹnətli wɝkt wɪð sɪlvɝ. ðə teɪbəl wɑz hɛvəli bɪlt, ɪts lɛɡz staʊt, bʌɾ ɪt sim tə skwɑɾ ʌndɝ ə weɪt tu stʃɹɔŋ mɛn wʊɾə hæd tʃɹʌbəl lɪftɪŋ.

The Amyrlin Seat herself sat behind a broad table in the middle of the carpet, and on the table rested a flattened cube of gold, the size of a travel chest and ornately worked with silver. The table was heavily built, its legs stout, but it seemed to squat under a weight two strong men would have had trouble lifting.

ət ðə saɪɾ ə ðə ɡoʊldən kjub mɔɪɹeɪn hæd dɪfəkəlti kipɪŋ əɹ feɪs ənɹʌfəld. ðə læst ʃi hæd sin ʌv ɪt, ɪt hæd bɪn seɪfli lɑkt ɪn eɪɡəlmɝz stʃɹɔŋɡɹum. ɑn lɝnɪŋ ə ði æmɪɝlɪn sits ɝaɪvəl ʃi hæd mɛn tə tɛl əɹ ʌv ɪt hɝsɛlf. ðəɾ ɪt wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ɪn ði æmɪɝlɪnz pəzɛʃən wɑz ə tʃɹaɪfəl, bʌɾ ə wɝisəm tʃɹaɪfəl. ɪvɛns kəd bi aʊtpeɪsɪŋ hɝ.

At the sight of the golden cube Moiraine had difficulty keeping her face unruffled. The last she had seen of it, it had been safely locked in Agelmar's strongroom. On learning of the Amyrlin Seat's arrival she had meant to tell her of it herself. That it was already in the Amyrlin's possession was a trifle, but a worrisome trifle. Events could be outpacing her.

ʃi swɛpt ə dip kɝtsi ən sɛd fɔɹməli, "æz jə kɔl mi, mʌðɝ, soʊ hæv aɪ kʌm." ði æmɪɝlɪn ɪkstɛndəɾ əɹ hænd, ən mɔɪɹeɪn kɪst əɹ ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ, noʊ dɪfɹən fɹəm ðəɾ ʌv ɛni ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɹaɪzɪŋ, ʃi meɪɾ əɹ toʊn mɔɹ kɑnvɝseɪʃənəl, bʌt nɑt tu mʌtʃ soʊ. ʃi wɑz əwɛɹ ə ðə kipɝ stændɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɝ, bɪsaɪd ðə dɔɹ. "aɪ hoʊp jə hæɾ ə plɛzən dʒɝni, mʌðɝ."

She swept a deep curtsy and said formally, "As you called me, Mother, so have I come." The Amyrlin extended her hand, and Moiraine kissed her Great Serpent ring, no different from that of any other Aes Sedai. Rising, she made her tone more conversational, but not too much so. She was aware of the Keeper standing behind her, beside the door. "I hope you had a pleasant journey, Mother."

ði æmɪɝlɪn hæd bɪn bɔɹn ɪn tiɹ, ʌv ə sɪmpəl fɪʃɝmænz fæmli, nɑɾ ə noʊbəl haʊs, ən əɹ neɪm wɑz sɪuən sɑntʃ, ðoʊ vɛɹi fju hæd juz ðət neɪm, əɹ ivən θɔɾ ʌv ɪt, ɪn ðə tɛn jɪɹz sɪns ʃi hæd bɪn ɹeɪz fɹəm ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ. ʃi wɑz ði æmɪɝlɪn sit; ðət wɑz ðə hoʊl ʌv ɪt. ðə bɹɔd stoʊl ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz wɑz stʃɹaɪpt ɪn ðə kʌlɝz ə ðə sɛvən ədʒəz; ði æmɪɝlɪn wɑz ʌv ɔl ədʒəz ən ə nʌn. ʃi wɑz oʊnli ʌv miɾiəm haɪt, ən hænsəm ɹæðɝ ðən bjuɾəfəl, bʌɾ əɹ feɪs hɛld ə stʃɹɛŋkθ ðət hæd bɪn ðəɹ bɪfɔɹ əɹ ɛləveɪʃən, ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ ə ðə ɡɝl u hæd sɝvaɪv ðə stʃɹits ə ðə mɔl, tɛɹz pɔɹt dɪstʃɹɪkt, ən əɹ klɪɹ blu ɡeɪz hæd meɪd kɪŋz ən kwinz, ən ivən ðə kæptən kəmændɝ ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt, dʒɹɑp ðɛɹ aɪz. hɝ oʊn aɪz wɝ stʃɹeɪnd, naʊ, ən ðəɹ wɑz ə nu taɪtnəs tə hɝ maʊθ.

The Amyrlin had been born in Tear, of a simple fisherman's family, not a noble House, and her name was Siuan Sanche, though very few had used that name, or even thought of it, in the ten years since she had been raised from the Hall of the Tower. She was the Amyrlin Seat; that was the whole of it. The broad stole on her shoulders was striped in the colors of the seven Ajahs; the Amyrlin was of all Ajahs and of none. She was only of medium height, and handsome rather than beautiful, but her face held a strength that had been there before her elevation, the strength of the girl who had survived the streets of the Maule, Tear's port district, and her clear blue gaze had made kings and queens, and even the Captain Commander of the Children of the Light, drop their eyes. Her own eyes were strained, now, and there was a new tightness to her mouth.

"wi kɔl ðə wɪnz tə spiɾ əɹ vɛsəlz ʌp ði ɛɹɪnɪn, dɔɾɝ, ən ivən tɝn ðə kɝəns tə əɹ eɪd." ði æmɪɝlɪnz vɔɪs wɑz dip, ən sæd. "aɪ hæv sin ðə flʌɾɪŋ wi kɑzd ɪn vɪlədʒəz əlɔŋ ðə ɹɪvɝ, ən ðə laɪɾ oʊnli noʊz wʌt wɪv dʌn tə ðə wɛðɝ. wɪl nɑɾ əv ɛndiɹɾ aʊɝsɛlvz baɪ ðə dæmədʒ wiv dʌn ən ðə kɹɑps wi meɪ hæv ɹuənd. ɔl tə ɹitʃ hɪɹ əz kwɪkli əz pɑsəbəl." hɝ aɪz stʃɹeɪd tə ði ɔɹneɪt ɡoʊldən kjub, ən ʃi hæf lɪftəɾ ə hæn əz ɪf tə tʌtʃ ɪt, bʌt wən ʃi spoʊk ɪt wɑz tə seɪ, "ɪleɪɾə ɪz ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn, dɔɾɝ. ʃi keɪm wɪð ɪleɪn ən ɡɔɪn."

"We called the winds to speed our vessels up the Erinin, Daughter, and even turned the currents to our aid." The Amyrlin's voice was deep, and sad. "I have seen the flooding we caused in villages along the river, and the Light only knows what we have done to the weather. We will not have endeared ourselves by the damage we've done and the crops we may have ruined. All to reach here as quickly as possible." Her eyes strayed to the ornate golden cube, and she half lifted a hand as if to touch it, but when she spoke it was to say, "Elaida is in Tar Valon, Daughter. She came with Elayne and Gawyn."

mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz kɑnʃəs ə lin stændɪŋ tə wʌn saɪd, kwaɪəɾ əz ɔlweɪz ɪn ðə pɹɛzəns ə ði æmɪɝlɪn. bʌt wɑtʃɪŋ, ən lɪsnɪŋ. "aɪ æm sɝpɹaɪzd, mʌðɝ," ʃi sɛd kɛɹfəli. "ðɪs ɪz noʊ taɪm fəɹ mɔɹɡeɪs tə bi wɪθaʊɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ kaʊnsəl." mɔɹɡeɪs wɑz wʌn ə ðə fju ɹulɝz tə oʊpənli ədmɪt tə ən ɛɛs sədaɪ kaʊnsəlɝ; ɔlmoʊst ɔl hæd wʌn, bʌt fju ədmɪɾəd ɪt.

Moiraine was conscious of Leane standing to one side, quiet as always in the presence of the Amyrlin. But watching, and listening. "I am surprised, Mother," she said carefully. "This is no time for Morgase to be without Aes Sedai counsel." Morgase was one of the few rulers to openly admit to an Aes Sedai councilor; almost all had one, but few admitted it.

"ɪleɪɾə ɪnsɪstəd, dɔɾɝ, ən kwin əɹ nɑt, aɪ daʊt mɔɹɡeɪs ɪz ə mætʃ fəɹ ɪleɪɾə ɪn ə kɑntɛst ʌv wɪlz. ɪn ɛni keɪs, pɝhæps ðɪs taɪm ʃi dɪd nɑt wɪʃ tə bi. ɪleɪn əz pətɛnʃəl. mɔɹ ðən aɪ hæv ɛvɝ sin bɪfɔɹ. ɔlɹɛɾi ʃi ʃoʊz pɹəɡɹɛs. ðə ɹɛd sɪstɝz ɑɹ swoʊlən ʌp laɪk pʌf-fɪʃ wɪð ɪt. aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðə ɡɝl linz tə ðɛɹ weɪ ʌv θɪŋkɪŋ, bʌt ʃiz jʌŋ, ən ðəɹ ɪz noʊ tɛlɪŋ. ivən ɪf ðeɪ doʊn mænədʒ tə bɛn hɝ, ɪɾəl meɪk lɪɾəl dɪfɝəns. ɪleɪn kəd wɛl bi ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ə θaʊzən jɪɹz, ən ɪts ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ hu faʊn hɝ. ðeɪv ɡeɪn mʌtʃ stæɾəs ɪn ðə hɔl fɹəm ðə ɡɝl."

"Elaida insisted, Daughter, and queen or not, I doubt Morgase is a match for Elaida in a contest of wills. In any case, perhaps this time she did not wish to be. Elayne has potential. More than I have ever seen before. Already she shows progress. The Red sisters are swollen up like puff-fish with it. I don't think the girl leans to their way of thinking, but she is young, and there is no telling. Even if they don't manage to bend her, it will make little difference. Elayne could well be the most powerful Aes Sedai in a thousand years, and it is the Red Ajah who found her. They have gained much status in the Hall from the girl."

"aɪ hæv tu jʌŋ wɪmən wɪð mi ɪn fæl dæɹə, mʌðɝ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "boʊθ fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, wɛɹ ðə blʌɾ ə meɪnɛðɝən stɪl ɹʌnz stʃɹɔŋ, ðoʊ ðeɪ də nɑɾ ivən ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðəɹ wɑz wʌns ə læn kɔl meɪnɛðɝən. ði oʊl blʌd sɪŋz, mʌðɝ, ən ɪt sɪŋz laʊdli ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. ɛɡwin, ə vɪlədʒ ɡɝl, ɪz ət list əz stʃɹɔŋ əz ɪleɪn. aɪ hæv sin ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ, ən aɪ noʊ. əz fəɹ ði ʌðɝ, nɪneɪiv wɑz ðə wɪzdəm ɪn ðɛɹ vɪlədʒ, jɛt ʃiz lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən ə ɡɝl hɝsɛlf. ɪt sɛz sʌmθɪŋ ə hɝ ðət ðə wɪmən ə hɝ vɪlədʒ tʃoʊz əɹ wɪzdəm əɾ əɹ eɪdʒ. wʌns ʃi ɡeɪnz kɑnʃəs kəntʃɹoʊl ʌv wʌt ʃi naʊ dʌz wɪθaʊt noʊɪŋ, ʃɪl bi əz stʃɹɔŋ əz ɛni ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn. wɪð tʃɹeɪnɪŋ, ʃɪl ʃaɪn laɪk ə bɑnfaɪɝ bɪsaɪd ðə kændəlz ʌv ɪleɪn ən ɛɡwin. ən ðəɹ ɪz noʊ tʃæns ðiz tu wɪl tʃuz ðə ɹɛd. ðeɪ ɑɹ əmjuz baɪ mɛn, ɪɡzæspɝeɪɾɪd baɪ ðɛm, bʌt ðeɪ də laɪk ðɛm. ðəl izəli kaʊntɝ wʌtɛvɝ ɪnfluəns ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ ɡeɪnz ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ fɹəm faɪndɪŋ ɪleɪn."

"I have two young women with me in Fal Dara, Mother," Moiraine said. "Both from the Two Rivers, where the blood of Manetheren still runs strong, though they do not even remember there was once a land called Manetheren. The old blood sings, Mother, and it sings loudly in the Two Rivers. Egwene, a village girl, is at least as strong as Elayne. I have seen the Daughter-Heir, and I know. As for the other, Nynaeve was the Wisdom in their village, yet she is little more than a girl herself. It says something of her that the women of her village chose her Wisdom at her age. Once she gains conscious control of what she now does without knowing, she will be as strong as any in Tar Valon. With training, she will shine like a bonfire beside the candles of Elayne and Egwene. And there is no chance these two will choose the Red. They are amused by men, exasperated by them, but they do like them. They will easily counter whatever influence the Red Ajah gains in the White Tower from finding Elayne."

ði æmɪɝlɪn nɑɾəd əz ɪf ɪt wɝ ɔl ə noʊ kɑnsəkwəns. mɔɪɹeɪnz aɪbɹaʊz lɪftəɾ ɪn sɝpɹaɪz bɪfɔɹ ʃi kɑt hɝsɛlf ən smuðd əɹ fitʃɝz. ðoʊz wɝ ðə tu meɪn kənsɝnz ɪn ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ, ðət fjuɝ ɡɝlz u kəd bi tʃɹeɪn tə tʃænəl ðə wʌn paʊɝ wɝ faʊn ɛvɹi jɪɹ, əɹ soʊ ɪt simd, ən ðət fjuɝ ə ɹil paʊɝ wɝ faʊnd. wɝs ðən ðə fɪɹ ɪn ðoʊz u bleɪmd ɛɛs sədaɪ fəɹ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld, wɝs ðən ðə heɪtʃɹəd fɹəm ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt, wɝs ivən ðən ðə wɝkɪŋz ə dɑɹkfɹɛnz, wɝ ðə ʃɪɹ dwɪndəlɪŋ ə nʌmbɝz ən ðə lɛsənɪŋ ʌv əbɪləɾiz. ðə kɔɹɪɾɝz ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ wɝ spɑɹsli pɑpjəleɪɾəd wɛɹ wʌns ðeɪ hæd bɪn kɹaʊɾəd, ən wʌt kəd wʌns bi dʌn izəli wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ kəd naʊ bi dʌn oʊnli wɪð dɪfəkəlti, əɹ nɑɾ əɾ ɔl.

The Amyrlin nodded as if it were all of no consequence. Moiraine's eyebrows lifted in surprise before she caught herself and smoothed her features. Those were the two main concerns in the Hall of the Tower, that fewer girls who could be trained to channel the One Power were found every year, or so it seemed, and that fewer of real power were found. Worse than the fear in those who blamed Aes Sedai for the Breaking of the World, worse than the hatred from the Children of the Light, worse even than the workings of Darkfriends, were the sheer dwindling of numbers and the lessening of abilities. The corridors of the White Tower were sparsely populated where once they had been crowded, and what could once be done easily with the One Power could now be done only with difficulty, or not at all.

"ɪleɪɾə hæɾ ənʌðɝ ɹizən fəɹ kʌmɪŋ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn, dɔɾɝ. ʃi sɛn ðə seɪm mɛsədʒ baɪ sɪks dɪfɹən pɪdʒənz tə meɪk ʃʊɹ aɪ ɹəsivd ɪt - ən tə hum ɛls ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn ʃi sɛn pɪdʒənz, aɪ kən oʊnli ɡɛs - ðən keɪm hɝsɛlf. ʃi toʊl ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ ðət jə ɑɹ mɛɾəlɪŋ wɪð ə jʌŋ mæn u ɪz tɑvɝən, ən deɪnʒɝəs. hi wɑz ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, ʃi sɛd, bʌt wən ʃi faʊn ði ɪn wɛɹ i hæd bɪn steɪɪŋ, ʃi dɪskʌvɝd jə hæd spɪɹəɾəd ɪm əweɪ."

"Elaida had another reason for coming to Tar Valon, Daughter. She sent the same message by six different pigeons to make sure I received it - and to whom else in Tar Valon she sent pigeons, I can only guess - then came herself. She told the Hall of the Tower that you are meddling with a young man who is ta'veren, and dangerous. He was in Caemlyn, she said, but when she found the inn where he had been staying, she discovered you had spirited him away."

"ðə pipəl ət ðəɾ ɪn sɝvd əs wɛl ən feɪθfəli, mʌðɝ. ɪf ʃi hɑɹmd ɛni ʌv ðɛm. . . ." mɔɪɹeɪn kəd nɑt kip ðə ʃɑɹpnəs aʊɾ ə hɝ vɔɪs, ən ʃi hɝd lin ʃɪft. wʌn dɪd nɑt spik tə ði æmɪɝlɪn siɾ ɪn ðət toʊn; nɑɾ ivən ə kɪŋ ɑn ɪz θɹoʊn dɪd.

"The people at that inn served us well and faithfully, Mother. If she harmed any of them. . . ." Moiraine could not keep the sharpness out of her voice, and she heard Leane shift. One did not speak to the Amyrlin Seat in that tone; not even a king on his throne did.

"ju ʃəd noʊ, dɔɾɝ," ði æmɪɝlɪn sɛd dʒɹaɪli, "ðæɾ ɪleɪɾə hɑɹmz noʊ wʌn ɪksɛp ðoʊz ʃi kənsɪɾɝz deɪnʒɝəs. dɑɹkfɹɛnz, əɹ ðoʊz pʊɹ ful mɛn u tʃɹaɪ tə tʃænəl ðə wʌn paʊɝ. əɹ wʌn u θɹɛɾənz tɑɹ vəlɑn. ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls u ɪzən ɛɛs sədaɪ maɪɾ əz wɛl bi pisəz ɑn ə stoʊnz bɔɹɾ əz fɑɹ əz ʃiz kənsɝnd. lʌkəli fəɹ hɪm, ði ɪnkipɝ, wʌn mæstɝ ɡɪl əz aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ, əpɛɹənli θɪŋks mʌtʃ ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən soʊ ænsɝɾ əɹ kwɛstʃənz tə hɝ sæɾəsfækʃən. ɪleɪɾə æktʃəli  spoʊk wɛl ə hɪm. bʌt ʃi spoʊk mɔɹ ə ðə jʌŋ mæn jə tʊk əweɪ wɪð ju. mɔɹ deɪnʒɝəs ðən ɛni mæn sɪns ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ, ʃi ʃiz hæz ðə fɔɹtɛlɪŋ səmtaɪmz, jə noʊ, ən əɹ wɝdz kæɹid weɪt wɪð ðə hɔl."

"You should know, Daughter," the Amyrlin said dryly, "that Elaida harms no one except those she considers dangerous. Darkfriends, or those poor fool men who try to channel the One Power. Or one who threatens Tar Valon. Everyone else who isn't Aes Sedai might as well be pieces on a stones board as far as she is concerned. Luckily for him, the innkeeper, one Master Gill as I remember, apparently thinks much of Aes Sedai, and so answered her questions to her satisfaction. Elaida actually spoke well of him. But she spoke more of the young man you took away with you. More dangerous than any man since Artur Hawkwing, she said. She has the Foretelling sometimes, you know, and her words carried weight with the Hall."

fəɹ linz seɪk, mɔɪɹeɪn meɪɾ əɹ vɔɪs əz mik əz ʃi kʊd. ðət wɑz nɑt vɛɹi mik, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðə bɛst ʃi kəd du. "aɪ hæv θɹi jʌŋ mɛn wɪð mi, mʌðɝ, bʌt nʌn ə ðɛm ɪz ə kɪŋ, ən ðəfɝs daʊt vɛɹi mʌtʃ ɪf ɛni ʌv əm ivən dʒɹimz ə junaɪɾɪŋ ðə wɝld ʌndɝ wʌn ɹulɝ. noʊ wʌn əz dʒɹimd ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz dʒɹim sɪns ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz."

For Leane's sake, Moiraine made her voice as meek as she could. That was not very meek, but it was the best she could do. "I have three young men with me, Mother, but none of them is a king, and I doubt very much if any of them even dreams of uniting the world under one ruler. No one has dreamed Artur Hawkwing's dream since the War of the Hundred Years."

"jɛs, dɔɾɝ. vɪlədʒ juðz, soʊ lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ tɛlz mi. bʌt wʌn ə ðɛm ɪz tɑvɝən." ði æmɪɝlɪnz aɪz stʃɹeɪd tə ðə flæɾənd kjub əɡɛn. "ɪt wɑz pʊt fɔɹwɝɾ ɪn ðə hɔl ðət jə ʃəd bi sɛn ɪndə ɹitʃɹit fəɹ kɑntəmpleɪʃən. ðɪs wɑz pɹəpoʊz baɪ wʌn ə ðə sɪɾɝz fəɹ ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ, wɪð ði ʌðɝ tu nɑɾɪŋ əpɹuvəl əz ʃi spoʊk."

"Yes, Daughter. Village youths, so Lord Agelmar tells me. But one of them is ta'veren." The Amyrlin's eyes strayed to the flattened cube again. "It was put forward in the Hall that you should be sent into retreat for contemplation. This was proposed by one of the Sitters for the Green Ajah, with the other two nodding approval as she spoke."

lin meɪɾ ə saʊn ə dɪsɡʌst, əɹ pɝhæps fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən. ʃi ɔlweɪz kɛpt ɪn ðə bækɡɹaʊnd wən ði æmɪɝlɪn sit spoʊk, bʌt mɔɪɹeɪn kəɾ ʌndɝstæn ðə smɔl ɪntɝʌpʃən ðɪs taɪm. ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ hæd bɪn əlaɪd wɪð ðə blu fəɹ ə θaʊzən jɪɹz; sɪns ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz taɪm, ðeɪ hæɾ ɔl bʌt spoʊkən wɪð wʌn vɔɪs. "aɪ hæv noʊ dɪzaɪɝ tə hoʊ vɛdʒtəbəlz ɪn səm ɹɪmoʊt vɪlədʒ, mʌðɝ." nɔɹ wɪl aɪ, wʌtɛvɝ ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ sɛz.

Leane made a sound of disgust, or perhaps frustration. She always kept in the background when the Amyrlin Seat spoke, but Moiraine could understand the small interruption this time. The Green Ajah had been allied with the Blue for a thousand years; since Artur Hawkwing's time, they had all but spoken with one voice. "I have no desire to hoe vegetables in some remote village, Mother." Nor will I, whatever the Hall of the Tower says.

"ɪt wɑz fɝðɝ pɹəpoʊzd, ɔlsoʊ baɪ ðə ɡɹinz, ðət jəɹ kɛɹ dʊɹɪŋ jəɹ ɹitʃɹit ʃəd bi ɡɪvən tə ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ. ðə ɹɛd sɪɾɝz tʃɹaɪd tə əpɪɹ sɝpɹaɪzd, bʌt ðeɪ lʊk laɪk fɪʃɝ-bɝdz u nu ðə kætʃ wɑz ənɡɑɹɾɪd." ði æmɪɝlɪn snɪft. "ðə ɹɛdz pɹəfɛst ɹɪlʌktəns tə teɪk kʌstəɾi ʌv wʌn nɑɾ ə ðɛɹ ədʒɑ, bʌt sɛd ðeɪ wəɾ æksid tə ðə wɪʃɪz ə ðə hɔl."

"It was further proposed, also by the Greens, that your care during your retreat should be given to the Red Ajah. The Red Sitters tried to appear surprised, but they looked like fisher-birds who knew the catch was unguarded." The Amyrlin sniffed. "The Reds professed reluctance to take custody of one not of their Ajah, but said they would accede to the wishes of the Hall."

dɪspaɪt hɝsɛlf, mɔɪɹeɪn ʃɪvɝd. "ðæt wəd bi . . . moʊst ənplɛzənt, mʌðɝ." ɪt wəd bi wɝs ðən ənplɛzənt, mʌtʃ wɝs; ðə ɹɛdz wɝ nɛvɝ dʒɛntəl. ʃi pʊt ðə θɔɾ ʌv ɪt fɝmli tə wʌn saɪd, tə dil wɪð leɪɾɝ. "mʌðɝ, aɪ kænɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ðɪs əpɛɹən əlaɪəns bɪtwin ðə ɡɹinz ən ðə ɹɛdz. ðɛɹ bɪlifs, ðɛɹ æɾətudz təwɔɹd mɛn, ðɛɹ vjuz ʌv əɹ vɛɹi pɝpəsəz əz ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɑɹ kəmplitli ɑpəzət. eɪ ɹɛɾ ən ə ɡɹin kænɑɾ ivən tɔk tə itʃ ʌðɝ wɪθaʊt kʌmɪŋ tə ʃaʊts."

Despite herself, Moiraine shivered. "That would be . . . most unpleasant, Mother." It would be worse than unpleasant, much worse; the Reds were never gentle. She put the thought of it firmly to one side, to deal with later. "Mother, I cannot understand this apparent alliance between the Greens and the Reds. Their beliefs, their attitudes toward men, their views of our very purposes as Aes Sedai, are completely opposite. A Red and a Green cannot even talk to each other without coming to shouts."

"θɪŋz tʃeɪnʒ, dɔɾɝ. fɔɹ ə ðə læs faɪv wɪmən ɹeɪzd æmɪɝlɪn əv kʌm fɹəm ðə blu. pɝhæps ðeɪ fil ðəɾ ɪz tu mɛni, əɹ ðət ðə blu weɪ ʌv θɪŋkɪŋ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ səfaɪsɪz ɪn ə wɝl fʊl ə fɔls dʒɹæɡənz. æftɝ ə θaʊzən jɪɹz, mɛni θɪŋz tʃeɪnʒ." ði æmɪɝlɪn ɡɹɪməst ən spoʊk əz ɪf tə hɝsɛlf. "oʊld wɔlz wikən, ən oʊl bæɹiɝz fɔl." ʃi ʃʊk hɝsɛlf, ən əɹ vɔɪs fɝmd. "ðɛɹ wɑz jɛɾ ənʌðɝ pɹəpoʊzəl, wʌn ðət stɪl smɛlz laɪk wik-oʊl fɪʃ ɑn ðə dʒɛɾi. sɪns lin ɪz ə ðə blu ədʒɑ ən aɪ keɪm fɹəm ðə blu, ɪt wɑz pʊt fɔɹwɝd ðət sɛndɪŋ tu sɪstɝz ə ðə blu wɪð mi ɑn ðɪs dʒɝni wəd ɡɪv ðə blu fɔɹ ɹɛpɹəzɛntəɾɪvz. pɹəpoʊzd ɪn ðə hɔl, tə maɪ feɪs, əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ dɪskʌsɪŋ ɹɪpɛɹɪŋ ðə dʒɹeɪnz. tu ʌv ðə waɪt sɪstɝz stʊɾ əɡɛns mi, ən tu ɡɹin. ðə jɛloʊ mʌɾɝd əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz, ðən wəd nɑt spik fəɹ əɹ əɡɛnst. wʌn mɔɹ seɪɪŋ neɪ, ən jəɹ sɪstɝz æneɪjə ən meɪɡɑn wəd nɑt bi hɪɹ. ðəɹ wɑz ivən səm tɔk, oʊpən tɔk, ðəɾ aɪ ʃəd nɑt liv ðə waɪt taʊɝ əɾ ɔl."

"Things change, Daughter. Four of the last five women raised Amyrlin have come from the Blue. Perhaps they feel that is too many, or that the Blue way of thinking no longer suffices in a world full of false Dragons. After a thousand years, many things change." The Amyrlin grimaced and spoke as if to herself. "Old walls weaken, and old barriers fall." She shook herself, and her voice firmed. "There was yet another proposal, one that still smells like week-old fish on the jetty. Since Leane is of the Blue Ajah and I came from the Blue, it was put forward that sending two sisters of the Blue with me on this journey would give the Blue four representatives. Proposed in the Hall, to my face, as if they were discussing repairing the drains. Two of the White Sisters stood against me, and two Green. The Yellow muttered among themselves, then would not speak for or against. One more saying nay, and your sisters Anaiya and Maigan would not be here. There was even some talk, open talk, that I should not leave the White Tower at all."

mɔɪɹeɪn fɛlt ə ɡɹeɪɾɝ ʃɑk ðən ɑn hɪɹɪŋ ðət ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ wɑntəɾ əɹ ɪn ðɛɹ hænz. wʌtɛvɝ ədʒɑ ʃi keɪm fɹʌm, ðə kipɝ ə ðə kɹɑnəkəlz spoʊk oʊnli fəɹ ði æmɪɝlɪn, ən ði æmɪɝlɪn spoʊk fəɹ ɔl ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ɔl ədʒəz. ðət wɑz ðə weɪ ɪt hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn, ən noʊ wʌn hæɾ ɛvɝ sədʒɛstəɾ ʌðɝwaɪz, nɑɾ ɪn ðə dɑɹkəs deɪz ə ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz, nɑt wən ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz ɑɹmiz hæd pɛn ɛvɹi sɝvaɪvɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪnsaɪd tɑɹ vəlɑn. əbʌv ɔl, ði æmɪɝlɪn sit wɑz ði æmɪɝlɪn sit. ɛvɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑz plɛdʒ tə oʊbeɪ hɝ. noʊ wʌn kəd kwɛstʃən wʌt ʃi dɪɾ əɹ wɛɹ ʃi tʃoʊz tə ɡoʊ. ðɪs pɹəpoʊzəl wɛn əɡɛns θɹi θaʊzən jɪɹz ə kʌstəm ən lɔ.

Moiraine felt a greater shock than on hearing that the Red Ajah wanted her in their hands. Whatever Ajah she came from, the Keeper of the Chronicles spoke only for the Amyrlin, and the Amyrlin spoke for all Aes Sedai and all Ajahs. That was the way it had always been, and no one had ever suggested otherwise, not in the darkest days of the Trolloc Wars, not when Artur Hawkwing's armies had penned every surviving Aes Sedai inside Tar Valon. Above all, the Amyrlin Seat was the Amyrlin Seat. Every Aes Sedai was pledged to obey her. No one could question what she did or where she chose to go. This proposal went against three thousand years of custom and law.

"hu wəd dɛɹ, mʌðɝ?"

"Who would dare, Mother?"

ði æmɪɝlɪn sits læf wɑz bɪɾɝ. "ɔlmoʊst ɛniwʌn, dɔɾɝ. ɹaɪəts ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. ðə ɡɹeɪt hʌn kɔld wɪθaʊɾ ɛni ʌv əs hævɪŋ ə hɪn ʌv ɪɾ əntɪl ðə pɹɑkləmeɪʃən. fɔls dʒɹæɡənz pɑpɪŋ ʌp laɪk ɹɛdbɛlz æftɝ ə ɹeɪn. neɪʃənz feɪɾɪŋ, ən mɔɹ noʊbəlz pleɪɪŋ ət ðə ɡeɪm ə haʊsəz ðən əɾ ɛni taɪm sɪns ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ kʌɾ ɔl ðɛɹ plɑɾɪŋz ʃɔɹt. ən wɝst ʌv ɔl, ɛvɹi wʌn ʌv əs noʊz ðə dɑɹk wʌn ɪz stɝɪŋ əɡɛn. ʃoʊ mi ə sɪstɝ u dʌz nɑt θɪŋk ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɪz luzɪŋ ɪts ɡɹɪp ɑn ɪvɛns, ən ɪf ʃiz nɑt bɹaʊn ədʒɑ, ʃiz dɛd. taɪm meɪ bi ɡɹoʊɪŋ ʃɔɹt fəɹ ɔl ʌv ʌs, dɔɾɝ. səmtaɪmz aɪ θɪŋk aɪ kən ɔlmoʊs fil ɪt ɡɹoʊɪŋ ʃɔɹɾɝ."

The Amyrlin Seat's laugh was bitter. "Almost anyone, Daughter. Riots in Caemlyn. The Great Hunt called without any of us having a hint of it until the proclamation. False Dragons popping up like redbells after a rain. Nations fading, and more nobles playing at the Game of Houses than at any time since Artur Hawkwing cut all their plottings short. And worst of all, every one of us knows the Dark One is stirring again. Show me a sister who does not think the White Tower is losing its grip on events, and if she is not Brown Ajah, she is dead. Time may be growing short for all of us, Daughter. Sometimes I think I can almost feel it growing shorter."

"æz jə seɪ, mʌðɝ, θɪŋz tʃeɪnʒ. bʌt ðəɹ ɑɹ stɪl wɝs pɛɹəlz aʊtsaɪd ðə ʃaɪnɪŋ wɔlz ðən wɪðɪn."

"As you say, Mother, things change. But there are still worse perils outside the Shining Walls than within."

fəɹ ə lɔŋ moʊmən ði æmɪɝlɪn mɛt mɔɪɹeɪnz ɡeɪz, ðən nɑɾəd sloʊli. "liv ʌs, lin. aɪ wəd tɔk tə maɪ dɔɾɝ mɔɪɹeɪn əloʊn."

For a long moment the Amyrlin met Moiraine's gaze, then nodded slowly. "Leave us, Leane. I would talk to my Daughter Moiraine alone."

ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli ə moʊməns hɛzəteɪʃən bɪfɔɹ lin sɛd, "æz jə wɪʃ, mʌðɝ." mɔɪɹeɪn kəd fil əɹ sɝpɹaɪz. ði æmɪɝlɪn ɡeɪv fju ɑɾiənsəz wɪθaʊt ðə kipɝ pɹɛzənt, ɪspɛʃli nɑt tə ə sɪstɝ ʃi hæd ɹizən tə tʃæstaɪz.

There was only a moment's hesitation before Leane said, "As you wish, Mother." Moiraine could feel her surprise. The Amyrlin gave few audiences without the Keeper present, especially not to a sister she had reason to chastise.

ðə dɔɹ oʊpən ən kloʊz bɪhaɪn lin. ʃi wəd nɑt seɪ ə wɝɾ ɪn ði æntəɹum ʌv wʌt hæɾ əkɝɾ ɪnsaɪd, bʌt ðə nuz ðət mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz əloʊn wɪð ði æmɪɝlɪn wəd spɹɛd θɹu ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn fæl dæɹə laɪk waɪldfaɪɝ θɹu ə dʒɹaɪ fɔɹəst, ən ðə spɛkjəleɪʃən wəd bɪɡɪn.

The door opened and closed behind Leane. She would not say a word in the anteroom of what had occurred inside, but the news that Moiraine was alone with the Amyrlin would spread through the Aes Sedai in Fal Dara like wildfire through a dry forest, and the speculation would begin.

əz sun əz ðə dɔɹ kloʊz ði æmɪɝlɪn stʊd, ən mɔɪɹeɪn fɛlt ə moʊməntɛɹi tɪŋɡəl ɪn əɹ skɪn əz ði ʌðɝ wʊmən tʃænəl ðə wʌn paʊɝ. fəɹ ən ɪnstənt, ði æmɪɝlɪn sit sim tə hɝ tə bi sɝaʊndəd baɪ ə nɪmbəs ə bɹaɪt laɪt.

As soon as the door closed the Amyrlin stood, and Moiraine felt a momentary tingle in her skin as the other woman channeled the One Power. For an instant, the Amyrlin Seat seemed to her to be surrounded by a nimbus of bright light.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ ðəɾ ɛni ʌv ði ʌðɝz əv jəɹ oʊl tʃɹɪk," ði æmɪɝlɪn sit sɛd, laɪtli tʌtʃɪŋ ðə blu stoʊn ɑn mɔɪɹeɪnz fɔɹhɛd wɪð wʌn fɪŋɡɝ, "bʌt moʊst ʌv əs əv səm smɔl tʃɹɪks ɹɪmɛmbɝd fɹəm tʃaɪldhʊd. ɪn ɛni ɪvɛnt, noʊ wʌn kən hɪɹ wʌt wi seɪ naʊ."

"I don't know that any of the others have your old trick," the Amyrlin Seat said, lightly touching the blue stone on Moiraine's forehead with one finger, "but most of us have some small tricks remembered from childhood. In any event, no one can hear what we say now."

sʌɾənli ʃi θɹu hɝ ɑɹmz ɝaʊn mɔɪɹeɪn, ə wɔɹm hʌɡ bɪtwin oʊl fɹɛnz; mɔɪɹeɪn hʌɡd bæk əz wɔɹmli.

Suddenly she threw her arms around Moiraine, a warm hug between old friends; Moiraine hugged back as warmly.

"ju ɑɹ ði oʊnli wʌn, mɔɪɹeɪn, wɪð hum aɪ kən ɹɪmɛmbɝ u aɪ wɑz. ivən lin ɔlweɪz æks əz ɪf aɪ hæd bɪkʌm ðə stoʊl ən ðə stæf, ivən wən wəɹ əloʊn, əz ɪf wid nɛvɝ ɡɪɡəl təɡɛðɝ əz nɑvəsɪz. səmtaɪmz aɪ wɪʃ wi stɪl wɝ nɑvəsɪz, jə ən aɪ. stɪl ɪnəsən ɪnʌf tə si ɪɾ ɔl əz ə ɡlimənz teɪl kʌm tʃɹu, stɪl ɪnəsən ɪnʌf tə θɪŋk wi wəd faɪn mɛn - ðeɪ wəd bi pɹɪnsəz, ɹɪmɛmbɝ, hænsəm ən stʃɹɔŋ ən dʒɛntəl? - hu kəd bɛɹ tə lɪv wɪð wɪmən ʌv ən ɛɛs sədaɪz paʊɝ. stɪl ɪnəsən ɪnʌf tə dʒɹim ə ðə hæpi ɛndɪŋ tə ðə ɡlimənz teɪl, ʌv lɪvɪŋ əɹ laɪvz əz ʌðɝ wɪmən du, dʒʌst wɪð mɔɹ ðən ðeɪ."

"You are the only one, Moiraine, with whom I can remember who I was. Even Leane always acts as if I had become the stole and the staff, even when we are alone, as if we'd never giggled together as novices. Sometimes I wish we still were novices, you and I. Still innocent enough to see it all as a gleeman's tale come true, still innocent enough to think we would find men - they would be princes, remember, handsome and strong and gentle? - who could bear to live with women of an Aes Sedai's power. Still innocent enough to dream of the happy ending to the gleeman's tale, of living our lives as other women do, just with more than they."

"wi ɑɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ, sɪuən. wɪv əɹ duɾi. ivən ɪf jə ən aɪ hæd nɑt bɪn bɔɹn tə tʃænəl, wəd jə ɡɪv ɪɾ ʌp fəɹ ə hoʊm ən ə hʌzbənd, ivən ə pɹɪns? aɪ də nɑt bɪliv ɪt. ðəɾ ɪz ə vɪlədʒ ɡʊdwaɪfs dʒɹim. nɑɾ ivən ðə ɡɹinz ɡoʊ soʊ fɑɹ."

"We are Aes Sedai, Siuan. We have our duty. Even if you and I had not been born to channel, would you give it up for a home and a husband, even a prince? I do not believe it. That is a village goodwife's dream. Not even the Greens go so far."

ði æmɪɝlɪn stɛp bæk. "noʊ, aɪ wəd nɑt ɡɪv ɪɾ ʌp. moʊst ə ðə taɪm, noʊ. bʌt ðəɹ əv bɪn taɪmz aɪ ɛnvid ðət vɪlədʒ ɡʊdwaɪf. ət ðɪs moʊmənt, aɪ ɔlmoʊs du. mɔɪɹeɪn, ɪf ɛniwʌn, ivən lin, dɪskʌvɝz wʌt wi plæn, wɪl boʊθ bi stɪld. ən aɪ kæn seɪ ðeɪ wəd bi ɹɔŋ tə də ɪt."

The Amyrlin stepped back. "No, I would not give it up. Most of the time, no. But there have been times I envied that village goodwife. At this moment, I almost do. Moiraine, if anyone, even Leane, discovers what we plan, we will both be stilled. And I can't say they would be wrong to do it."


tʃæptɝ faɪv


CHAPTER 5

ðə ʃædoʊ ɪn ʃaɪnɝ


The Shadow in Shienar

stɪld. ðə wɝd sim tə kwɪvɝ ɪn ði ɛɹ, ɔlmoʊs vɪzəbəl. wən ɪt wɑz dʌn tə ə mæn u kəd tʃænəl ðə paʊɝ, hu mʌs bi stɑp bɪfɔɹ mædnəs dʒɹoʊv ɪm tə ðə dɪstʃɹʌkʃən ʌv ɔl ɝaʊn hɪm, ɪt wɑz kɔl dʒɛntəlɪŋ, bʌt fəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪt wɑz stɪlɪŋ. stɪld. noʊ lɔŋɡɝ eɪbəl tə tʃænəl ðə floʊ ʌv ðə wʌn paʊɝ. eɪbəl tə sɛns seɪaɪdɑɹ, ðə fimeɪl hæf ə ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs, bʌt noʊ lɔŋɡɝ hævɪŋ ði əbɪləɾi tə tʌtʃ ɪt. ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ wʌt wɑz ɡɔn fɝɛvɝ. soʊ sɛldəm hæɾ ɪt bɪn dʌn ðəɾ ɛvɹi nɑvəs wɑz ɹikwaɪɝd tə lɝn ðə neɪm ʌv itʃ ɛɛs sədaɪ sɪns ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld u hæd bɪn stɪld, ən əɹ kɹaɪm, bʌt nʌn kəd θɪŋk ʌv ɪt wɪθaʊɾ ə ʃʌɾɝ. wɪmən bɔɹ biɪŋ stɪl noʊ bɛɾɝ ðən mɛn dɪd biɪŋ dʒɛntəld.

Stilled. The word seemed to quiver in the air, almost visible. When it was done to a man who could channel the Power, who must be stopped before madness drove him to the destruction of all around him, it was called gentling, but for Aes Sedai it was stilling. Stilled. No longer able to channel the flow of the One Power. Able to sense saidar, the female half of the True Source, but no longer having the ability to touch it. Remembering what was gone forever. So seldom had it been done that every novice was required to learn the name of each Aes Sedai since the Breaking of the World who had been stilled, and her crime, but none could think of it without a shudder. Women bore being stilled no better than men did being gentled.

mɔɪɹeɪn hæd noʊn ðə ɹɪsk fɹəm ðə fɝst, ən ʃi nu ɪt wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi. ðət dɪd nɑt min ɪt wɑz plɛzən tə dwɛl ɑn. hɝ aɪz nɛɹoʊd, ən oʊnli ðə ɡlim ɪn əm ʃoʊɾ əɹ æŋɡɝ, ən əɹ wɝi. "lin wəd fɑloʊ jə tə ðə sloʊps ə ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl, sɪuən, ən ɪndə ðə pɪɾ ə dum. jə kænɑt θɪŋk ʃi wəd bɪtʃɹeɪ ju."

Moiraine had known the risk from the first, and she knew it was necessary. That did not mean it was pleasant to dwell on. Her eyes narrowed, and only the gleam in them showed her anger, and her worry. "Leane would follow you to the slopes of Shayol Ghul, Siuan, and into the Pit of Doom. You cannot think she would betray you."

"noʊ. bʌt ðɛn, wəd ʃi θɪŋk ɪt bɪtʃɹeɪəl? ɪz ɪt bɪtʃɹeɪəl tə bɪtʃɹeɪ ə tʃɹeɪɾɝ? dʒju nɛvɝ θɪŋk ə ðæt?"

"No. But then, would she think it betrayal? Is it betrayal to betray a traitor? Do you never think of that?"

"nɛvɝ. wʌt wi du, sɪuən, ɪz wʌt mʌs bi dʌn. wɪv boʊθ noʊn ɪt fəɹ nɪɹli twɛnti jɪɹz. ðə wil wivz əz ðə wil wɪlz, ən jə ən aɪ wɝ tʃoʊzən fəɹ ðɪs baɪ ðə pæɾɝn. wəɹ ə pɑɹɾ ə ðə pɹɑfəsiz, ən ðə pɹɑfəsiz mʌs bi fʊlfɪld. mʌst!"

"Never. What we do, Siuan, is what must be done. We have both known it for nearly twenty years. The Wheel weaves as the Wheel wills, and you and I were chosen for this by the Pattern. We are a part of the Prophecies, and the Prophecies must be fulfilled. Must!"

"ðə pɹɑfəsiz mʌs bi fʊlfɪld. wi wɝ tɔt ðət ðəl bi, ən mʌs bi, ən jɛt ðət fʊlfɪlmən ɪz tʃɹizən tə ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls wi wɝ tɔt. səm wəd seɪ tə ɛvɹiθɪŋ wi stæn fɔɹ." ɹʌbɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz, ði æmɪɝlɪn sit wɔkt oʊvɝ tə pɪɹ θɹu ðə nɛɹoʊ æɹoʊslɪɾ ət ðə ɡɑɹɾən bɪloʊ. ʃi tʌtʃt ðə kɝɾənz. "hɪɹ ɪn ðə wɪmənz əpɑɹtməns ðeɪ hæŋ dʒɹeɪpɝiz tə sɑfən ðə ɹumz, ən ðeɪ plæn bjuɾəfəl ɡɑɹɾənz, bʌt ðəɹ ɪz noʊ pɑɹɾ ə ðɪs pleɪs nɑt pɝpəs-meɪd fəɹ bæɾəl, dɛθ, ən kɪlɪŋ." ʃi kəntɪnjuɾ ɪn ðə seɪm pɛnsɪv toʊn. "oʊnli twaɪs sɪns ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld əz ði æmɪɝlɪn sit bɪn stʃɹɪpt ə stoʊl ən stæf."

"The Prophecies must be fulfilled. We were taught that they will be, and must be, and yet that fulfillment is treason to everything else we were taught. Some would say to everything we stand for." Rubbing her arms, the Amyrlin Seat walked over to peer through the narrow arrowslit at the garden below. She touched the curtains. "Here in the women's apartments they hang draperies to soften the rooms, and they plant beautiful gardens, but there is no part of this place not purpose-made for battle, death, and killing." She continued in the same pensive tone. "Only twice since the Breaking of the World has the Amyrlin Seat been stripped of stole and staff."

"tɛtsuən, hu bɪtʃɹeɪd meɪnɛðɝən fəɹ dʒɛləsi ʌv ɛlɪsɑnz paʊɝz, ən bɑnwɪn, hu tʃɹaɪd tə juz ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ fəɹ ə pʌpət tə kəntʃɹoʊl ðə wɝld ən soʊ nɪɹli dɪstʃɹɔɪd tɑɹ vəlɑn."

"Tetsuan, who betrayed Manetheren for jealousy of Ellisande's powers, and Bonwhin, who tried to use Artur Hawkwing for a puppet to control the world and so nearly destroyed Tar Valon."

ði æmɪɝlɪn kəntɪnjuɾ əɹ stʌɾi ʌv ðə ɡɑɹɾən. "boʊθ ə ðə ɹɛd, ən boʊθ ɹipleɪs baɪ æmɪɝlɪn fɹəm ðə blu. ðə ɹizən ðəɹ əz nɑt bɪn ən æmɪɝlɪn tʃoʊzən fɹəm ðə ɹɛd sɪns bɑnwɪn, ən ðə ɹizən ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ wɪl teɪk ɛni pɹitɛks tə pʊl daʊn ən æmɪɝlɪn fɹəm ðə blu, ɔl ɹæp nitli təɡɛðɝ. aɪ hæv noʊ wɪʃ tə bi ðə θɝd tə luz ðə stoʊl ən ðə stæf, mɔɪɹeɪn. fəɹ ju, ʌv kɔɹs, ɪt wəd min biɪŋ stɪld ən pʊɾ aʊtsaɪd ðə ʃaɪnɪŋ wɔlz."

The Amyrlin continued her study of the garden. "Both of the Red, and both replaced by Amyrlin from the Blue. The reason there has not been an Amyrlin chosen from the Red since Bonwhin, and the reason the Red Ajah will take any pretext to pull down an Amyrlin from the Blue, all wrapped neatly together. I have no wish to be the third to lose the stole and the staff, Moiraine. For you, of course, it would mean being stilled and put outside the Shining Walls."

"ɪleɪɾə, fəɹ wʌn, wəd nɛvɝ lemi ɔf soʊ izəli." mɔɪɹeɪn wɑtʃt əɹ fɹɛnz bæk ɪntɛnli. laɪt, wʌɾ əz kʌm oʊvɝ hɝ? ʃiz nɛvɝ bɪn laɪk ðɪs bɪfɔɹ. wɛɹ ɪz əɹ stʃɹɛŋkθ, hɝ faɪɝ? "bʌɾ ɪɾəl nɑt kʌm tə ðæt, sɪuən."

"Elaida, for one, would never let me off so easily." Moiraine watched her friend's back intently. Light, what has come over her? She has never been like this before. Where is her strength, her fire? "But it will not come to that, Siuan."

ði ʌðɝ wʊmən wɛn ɑn əz ɪf ʃi hæd nɑt spoʊkən. "fɔɹ mi, ɪt wəd bi dɪfɹənt. ivən stɪld, ən æmɪɝlɪn u hæz bɪn pʊl daʊn kænɑt bi əlaʊd tə wɑndɝ əbaʊt lus; ʃi maɪt bi sin əz ə mɑɹɾɝ, bɪkʌm ə ɹæliɪŋ pɔɪn fəɹ ɑpəzɪʃən. tɛtsuən ən bɑnwɪn wɝ kɛpt ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ əz sɝvəns. skʌlɝi meɪdz, hu kəd bi pɔɪntəd tə əz kɔʃənz əz tə wʌt kən hæpən tə ðə maɪɾiəst. noʊ wʌn kən ɹæli ɝaʊn ə wʊmən u mʌst skɹʌb flɔɹz ən pɑts ɔl deɪ. pɪɾi hɝ, jɛs, bʌt nɑt ɹæli tə hɝ."

The other woman went on as if she had not spoken. "For me, it would be different. Even stilled, an Amyrlin who has been pulled down cannot be allowed to wander about loose; she might be seen as a martyr, become a rallying point for opposition. Tetsuan and Bonwhin were kept in the White Tower as servants. Scullery maids, who could be pointed to as cautions as to what can happen to the mightiest. No one can rally around a woman who must scrub floors and pots all day. Pity her, yes, but not rally to her."

aɪz bleɪzɪŋ, mɔɪɹeɪn lin əɹ fɪsts ɑn ðə teɪbəl. "lʊk ət mi, sɪuən. lʊk ət mi! ɑɹ jə seɪɪŋ ðət jə wɑnə ɡɪv ʌp, æftɝ ɔl ðiz jɪɹz, æftɝ ɔl wɪv dʌn? ɡɪv ʌp, ən lɛt ðə wɝld ɡoʊ? ən ɔl fəɹ fɪɹ ʌv ə swɪtʃɪŋ fəɹ nɑt ɡɛɾɪŋ ðə pɑts klin ɪnʌf!" ʃi pʊɾ ɪndə ɪɾ ɔl ðə skɔɹn ʃi kəd sʌmən, ən wɑz ɹɪlivd wən əɹ fɹɛn spʌn tə feɪs hɝ. ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ wɑz stɪl ðɛɹ, stʃɹeɪn bʌt stɪl ðɛɹ. ðoʊz klɪɹ blu aɪz wɝ əz hɑt wɪð æŋɡɝ əz əɹ oʊn.

Eyes blazing, Moiraine leaned her fists on the table. "Look at me, Siuan. Look at me! Are you saying that you want to give up, after all these years, after all we have done? Give up, and let the world go? And all for fear of a switching for not getting the pots clean enough!" She put into it all the scorn she could summon, and was relieved when her friend spun to face her. The strength was still there, strained but still there. Those clear blue eyes were as hot with anger as her own.

"aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ wɪtʃ ə ðə tu ʌv əs skwil ðə laʊɾəst wən wi wɝ swɪtʃt əz nɑvəsɪz. jə hæd lɪvd ə sɑf laɪf ɪn kɛɹhin, mɔɪɹeɪn. nɑt laɪk wɝkɪŋ ə fɪʃɪŋ boʊt." əbɹʌpli sɪuən slæp ðə teɪbəl wɪð ə laʊd kɹæk. "noʊ, aɪm nɑt sədʒɛstɪŋ ɡɪvɪŋ ʌp, bʌt niðɝ də aɪ pɹəpoʊz tə wɑtʃ ɛvɹiθɪŋ slaɪɾ aʊɾ ʌv əɹ hænz waɪl aɪ kən də nʌθɪŋ! moʊst ə maɪ tʃɹʌbəlz wɪð ðə hɔl stɛm fɹəm ju. ivən ðə ɡɹinz wʌndɝ waɪ aɪ hævən kɔl jə tə ðə taʊɝ ən tɔt jə ə lɪɾəl dɪsəplən. hæf ðə sɪstɝz wɪð mi θɪŋk jə ʃəd bi hændəɾ oʊvɝ tə ðə ɹɛdz, ən ɪf ðət hæpənz, jəl wɪʃ jə wɝ ə nɑvəs əɡɛn, wɪð nʌθɪŋ wɝs tə lʊk fɔɹwɝd tə ðən ə swɪtʃɪŋ. laɪt! ɪf ɛni ʌv əm ɹɪmɛmbɝ wi wɝ fɹɛnz əz nɑvəsɪz, aɪd bi ðəɹ bɪsaɪd ju.

"I remember which of the two of us squealed the loudest when we were switched as novices. You had lived a soft life in Cairhien, Moiraine. Not like working a fishing boat." Abruptly Siuan slapped the table with a loud crack. "No, I am not suggesting giving up, but neither do I propose to watch everything slide out of our hands while I can do nothing! Most of my troubles with the Hall stem from you. Even the Greens wonder why I haven't called you to the Tower and taught you a little discipline. Half the sisters with me think you should be handed over to the Reds, and if that happens, you will wish you were a novice again, with nothing worse to look forward to than a switching. Light! If any of them remember we were friends as novices, I'd be there beside you.

"wi hæɾ ə plæn! ə plæn, mɔɪɹeɪn! loʊkeɪt ðə bɔɪ ən bɹɪŋ ɪm tə tɑɹ vəlɑn, wɛɹ wi kəd haɪd hɪm, kip ɪm seɪf ən ɡaɪd hɪm. sɪns jə lɛf ðə taʊɝ, aɪ hæv hæɾ oʊnli tu mɛsədʒəz fɹəm ju. tu! aɪ fil əz ɪf aɪm tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə seɪl ðə fɪŋɡɝz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɪn ðə dɑɹk. wʌn mɛsədʒ tə seɪ jə wɝ ɛntɝɪŋ ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, ɡoʊɪŋ tə ðɪs vɪlədʒ, ðɪs ɛmənz fild. sun, aɪ θɔt. hiz faʊnd, ən ʃɪl əv ɪm ɪn hæn sun. ðən wɝd fɹəm keɪɛmlɪn tə seɪ jə wɝ kʌmɪŋ tə ʃaɪnɝ, tə fæl dæɹə, nɑt tɑɹ vəlɑn. fæl dæɹə, wɪð ðə blaɪɾ ɔlmoʊs kloʊs ɪnʌf tə tʌtʃ. fæl dæɹə, wɛɹ tʃɹɑləks ɹeɪɾ ən mɹdʒɹɑl ɹaɪɾ əz nɪɹ ɛvɹi deɪ əz meɪks noʊ dɪfɝəns. nɪɹli twɛnti jɪɹz ə plænɪŋ ən sɝtʃɪŋ, ən jə tɔs ɔl əɹ plænz pɹæktəkli ɪn ðə dɑɹk wʌnz feɪs. ɑɹ jə mæd?"

"We had a plan! A plan, Moiraine! Locate the boy and bring him to Tar Valon, where we could hide him, keep him safe and guide him. Since you left the Tower, I have had only two messages from you. Two! I feel as if I'm trying to sail the Fingers of the Dragon in the dark. One message to say you were entering the Two Rivers, going to this village, this Emond's Field. Soon, I thought. He's found, and she'll have him in hand soon. Then word from Caemlyn to say you were coming to Shienar, to Fal Dara, not Tar Valon. Fal Dara, with the Blight almost close enough to touch. Fal Dara, where Trollocs raid and Myrddraal ride as near every day as makes no difference. Nearly twenty years of planning and searching, and you toss all our plans practically in the Dark One's face. Are you mad?"

naʊ ðət ʃi hæd stɝd laɪf ɪn ði ʌðɝ wʊmən, mɔɪɹeɪn ɹɪtɝn tə aʊtwɝd kɑm, hɝsɛlf. kɑm, bʌt fɝm ɪnsɪstəns, tu. "ðə pæɾɝn peɪz noʊ hid tə hjumən plænz, sɪuən. wɪð ɔl əɹ skimɪŋ, wi fɝɡɑt wʌt wi wɝ dilɪŋ wɪð. tɑvɝən. ɪleɪɾə ɪz ɹɔŋ. ɑɹɾɝ pɛndʒɹæɡ tænɹəl wɑz nɛvɝ ðɪs stʃɹɔŋli tɑvɝən. ðə wil wɪl wiv ðə pæɾɝn ɝaʊn ðɪs jʌŋ mæn əz ɪt wɪlz, wʌtɛvɝ əɹ plænz."

Now that she had stirred life in the other woman, Moiraine returned to outward calm, herself. Calm, but firm insistence, too. "The Pattern pays no heed to human plans, Siuan. With all our scheming, we forgot what we were dealing with. Ta'veren. Elaida is wrong. Artur Paendrag Tanreall was never this strongly ta'veren. The Wheel will weave the Pattern around this young man as it wills, whatever our plans."

ði æŋɡɝ lɛft æmɪɝlɪnz feɪs, ɹipleɪs baɪ waɪt-feɪst ʃɑk. "ɪt saʊnz əz ɪf jə ɑɹ seɪɪŋ wi maɪɾ əz wɛl ɡɪv ʌp. dʒju naʊ sədʒɛst stændɪŋ əsaɪɾ ən wɑtʃɪŋ ðə wɝl bɝn?"

The anger left Amyrlin's face, replaced by white-faced shock. "It sounds as if you are saying we might as well give up. Do you now suggest standing aside and watching the world burn?"

"noʊ, sɪuən. nɛvɝ stændɪŋ əsaɪd." jɛt ðə wɝld wɪl bɝn, sɪuən, wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ, wʌtɛvɝ wi du. jə kəd nɛvɝ si ðæt. "bʌt wi mʌs naʊ ɹilaɪz ðəɾ əɹ plænz ɑɹ pɹikɛɹiəs θɪŋz. wɪv ivən lɛs kəntʃɹoʊl ðən wi θɔt. pɝhæps oʊnli ə fɪŋɡɝneɪlz ɡɹɪp. ðə wɪnz ə dɛstəni ɑɹ bloʊɪŋ, sɪuən, ən wi mʌst ɹaɪɾ əm wɛɹ ðeɪ teɪk ʌs."

"No, Siuan. Never standing aside." Yet the world will burn, Siuan, one way or another, whatever we do. You could never see that. "But we must now realize that our plans are precarious things. We have even less control than we thought. Perhaps only a fingernail's grip. The winds of destiny are blowing, Siuan, and we must ride them where they take us."

ði æmɪɝlɪn ʃɪvɝɾ əz ɪf ʃi fɛl ðoʊz wɪnz aɪsi ɑn ðə bæk ə hɝ nɛk. hɝ hænz wɛn tə ðə flæɾənd kjub ʌv ɡoʊld, blʌnt, keɪpəbəl fɪŋɡɝz faɪndɪŋ pɹɪsaɪs pɔɪns ɪn ðə kɑmplɛks dɪzaɪnz. kʌnɪŋli bælənst, ðə tɑp lɪftəd bæk tə ɹɪvil ə kɝld, ɡoʊldən hɔɹn nɛsəld wɪðɪn ə speɪs dɪzaɪn tə hoʊld ɪt. ʃi lɪftəd ði ɪnstʃɹəmən ən tʃɹeɪs ðə floʊɪŋ sɪlvɝ skɹɪpt, ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, ɪnleɪɾ ɝaʊn ðə flɛɹɪŋ maʊθ.

The Amyrlin shivered as if she felt those winds icy on the back of her neck. Her hands went to the flattened cube of gold, blunt, capable fingers finding precise points in the complex designs. Cunningly balanced, the top lifted back to reveal a curled, golden horn nestled within a space designed to hold it. She lifted the instrument and traced the flowing silver script, in the Old Tongue, inlaid around the flaring mouth.

" 'ðə ɡɹeɪv ɪz noʊ bɑɹ tə maɪ kɔl,' " ʃi tʃɹænzleɪɾəd, soʊ sɔfli ʃi sim tə bi spikɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf. "ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ, meɪd tə kɔl dɛd hɪɹoʊz bæk fɹəm ðə ɡɹeɪv. ən pɹɑfəsi sɛɾ ɪt wəɾ oʊnli bi faʊn dʒʌst ɪn taɪm fəɹ ðə læs bæɾəl." əbɹʌpli ʃi θɹʌs ðə hɔɹn bæk ɪndə ɪts nɪtʃ ən kloʊz ðə lɪɾ əz ɪf ʃi kəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ bɛɹ ðə saɪɾ ʌv ɪt. "eɪɡəlmɝ pʊʃt ɪɾ ɪndə maɪ hænz əz sun əz ðə wɛlkəm wɑz dʌn. hi sɛɾ i wɑz əfɹeɪd tə ɡoʊ ɪndə hɪz oʊn stʃɹɔŋɡɹum ɛni lɔŋɡɝ, wɪð ɪt ðɛɹ. ðə tɛmteɪʃən wɑz tu ɡɹeɪt, hi sɛd. tə saʊn ðə hɔɹn hɪmsɛlf ən lɛd ðə hoʊs ðəɾ ænsɝɾ ɪts kɔl nɔɹθ θɹu ðə blaɪt tə lɛvəl ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl ɪtsɛlf ən pʊɾ ən ɛn tə ðə dɑɹk wʌn. hi bɝnd wɪð ði ɛkstəsi ʌv ɡlɔɹi, ən ɪt wɑz ðæt, hi sɛd, ðət toʊld ɪm ɪt wɑz nɑt tə bi hɪm, mʌs nɑt bi hɪm. hi kəd nɑt weɪt tə bi ɹɪɾ ʌv ɪt, jɛɾ i wɑntəɾ ɪt stɪl."

" 'The grave is no bar to my call,' " she translated, so softly she seemed to be speaking to herself. "The Horn of Valere, made to call dead heroes back from the grave. And prophecy said it would only be found just in time for the Last Battle." Abruptly she thrust the Horn back into its niche and closed the lid as if she could no longer bear the sight of it. "Agelmar pushed it into my hands as soon as the Welcome was done. He said he was afraid to go into his own strongroom any longer, with it there. The temptation was too great, he said. To sound the Horn himself and lead the host that answered its call north through the Blight to level Shayol Ghul itself and put an end to the Dark One. He burned with the ecstasy of glory, and it was that, he said, that told him it was not to be him, must not be him. He could not wait to be rid of it, yet he wanted it still."

mɔɪɹeɪn nɑɾəd. eɪɡəlmɝ wɑz fəmɪljɝ wɪð ðə pɹɑfəsi ʌv ðə hɔɹn; moʊst u fɔt ðə dɑɹk wʌn wɝ. " 'lɛt husoʊɛvɝ saʊnz mi θɪŋk nɑɾ ʌv ɡlɔɹi, bʌɾ oʊnli ʌv sælveɪʃən.' "

Moiraine nodded. Agelmar was familiar with the Prophecy of the Horn; most who fought the Dark One were. " 'Let whosoever sounds me think not of glory, but only of salvation.' "

"sælveɪʃən." ði æmɪɝlɪn læf bɪɾɝli. "fɹʌm ðə lʊk ɪn eɪɡəlmɝz aɪz, hi dɪdnt noʊ wɛðɝ i wɑz ɡɪvɪŋ əweɪ sælveɪʃən əɹ ɹɪdʒɛktɪŋ ðə kɑndəmneɪʃən ə hɪz oʊn soʊl. hi oʊnli nu hi hæd tə bi ɹɪɾ ʌv ɪt bɪfɔɹ ɪt bɝn ɪm ʌp. hiz tʃɹaɪd tə kip ɪt sikɹət, bʌɾ i sɛz ðəɹ ɑɹ ɹumɝz ɪn ðə kip ɔlɹɛɾi. aɪ də nɑt fil ɪz tɛmteɪʃən, jɛt ðə hɔɹn stɪl meɪks maɪ skɪn kɹɔl. hɪl əv tə teɪk ɪt bæk ɪndə hɪz stʃɹɔŋɡɹum əntɪl aɪ liv. aɪ kəd nɑt slip wɪð ɪɾ ivən ɪn ðə nɛkst ɹum." ʃi ɹʌb fɹaʊn laɪnz fɹəm əɹ fɔɹhɛɾ ən saɪd. "æn ɪt wɑz nɑt tə bi faʊn əntɪl dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ ðə læs bæɾəl. kən ɪt bi ðət kloʊs? aɪ θɔt, hoʊpt, wi wəɾ əv mɔɹ taɪm."

"Salvation." The Amyrlin laughed bitterly. "From the look in Agelmar's eyes, he didn't know whether he was giving away salvation or rejecting the condemnation of his own soul. He only knew he had to be rid of it before it burned him up. He has tried to keep it secret, but he says there are rumors in the keep already. I do not feel his temptation, yet the Horn still makes my skin crawl. He will have to take it back into his strongroom until I leave. I could not sleep with it even in the next room." She rubbed frown lines from her forehead and sighed. "And it was not to be found until just before the Last Battle. Can it be that close? I thought, hoped, we would have more time."

"ðə kæɹæəθən saɪkəl."

"The Karaethon Cycle."

"jɛs, mɔɪɹeɪn. jə də nɑɾ əv tə ɹimaɪn mi. aɪv lɪvd wɪð ðə pɹɑfəsiz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən əz lɔŋ əz ju." ði æmɪɝlɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "nɛvɝ mɔɹ ðən wʌn fɔls dʒɹæɡən ɪn ə dʒɛnɝeɪʃən sɪns ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ, ən naʊ θɹi lus ɪn ðə wɝld ət wʌn taɪm, ən θɹi mɔɹ ɪn ðə pæs tu jɪɹz. ðə pæɾɝn dɪmænz ə dʒɹæɡən kəz ðə pæɾɝn wivz təwɔɹd tɑɹmən ɡdən. səmtaɪmz daʊt fɪlz mi, mɔɪɹeɪn." ʃi sɛɾ ɪt mjuzɪŋli, əz ɪf wʌndɝɪŋ əɾ ɪt, ən wɛn ɑn ɪn ðə seɪm toʊn. "wʌɾ ɪf lɑɡən wɑz ðə wʌn? hi kəd tʃænəl, bɪfɔɹ ðə ɹɛdz bɹɔɾ ɪm tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ən wi dʒɛntəl hɪm. soʊ kən mæzɹim teɪm, ðə mæn ɪn sɑldɑiə. wʌɾ ɪf ɪts hɪm? ðəɹ ɑɹ sɪstɝz ɪn sɑldɑiə ɔlɹɛɾi; hi meɪ bi teɪkən baɪ naʊ. wʌɾ ɪf wɪv bɪn ɹɔŋ sɪns ðə stɑɹt? wʌt hæpənz ɪf ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɪz dʒɛntəl bɪfɔɹ ðə læs bæɾəl ivən bɪɡɪnz? ivən pɹɑfəsi kən feɪl ɪf ðə wʌn pɹɑfəsaɪɾ ɪz sleɪn əɹ dʒɛntəld. ən ðən wi feɪs ðə dɑɹk wʌn neɪkəd tə ðə stɔɹm."

"Yes, Moiraine. You do not have to remind me. I've lived with the Prophecies of the Dragon as long as you." The Amyrlin shook her head. "Never more than one false Dragon in a generation since the Breaking, and now three loose in the world at one time, and three more in the past two years. The Pattern demands a Dragon because the Pattern weaves toward Tarmon Gai'don. Sometimes doubt fills me, Moiraine." She said it musingly, as if wondering at it, and went on in the same tone. "What if Logain was the one? He could channel, before the Reds brought him to the White Tower, and we gentled him. So can Mazrim Taim, the man in Saldaea. What if it is him? There are sisters in Saldaea already; he may be taken by now. What if we have been wrong since the start? What happens if the Dragon Reborn is gentled before the Last Battle even begins? Even prophecy can fail if the one prophesied is slain or gentled. And then we face the Dark One naked to the storm."

"niðɝ ə ðɛm ɪz ðə wʌn, sɪuən. ðə pæɾɝn dʌz nɑt dɪmæn ə dʒɹæɡən, bʌt ðə wʌn tʃɹu dʒɹæɡən. əntɪl i pɹoʊkleɪmz hɪmsɛlf, ðə pæɾɝn wɪl kəntɪnju tə θɹoʊ ʌp fɔls dʒɹæɡənz, bʌɾ æftɝ ðət ðəɹ wɪl bi noʊ ʌðɝz. ɪf lɑɡən əɹ ði ʌðɝ wɝ ðə wʌn, ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ ʌðɝz."

"Neither of them is the one, Siuan. The Pattern does not demand a Dragon, but the one true Dragon. Until he proclaims himself, the Pattern will continue to throw up false Dragons, but after that there will be no others. If Logain or the other were the one, there would be no others."

" 'fɔɹ i ʃæl kʌm laɪk ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ dɔn, ən ʃæɾɝ ðə wɝld əɡɛn wɪð ɪz kʌmɪŋ, ən meɪk ɪɾ ənu.' iðɝ wi ɡoʊ neɪkəɾ ɪn ðə stɔɹm, əɹ klɪŋ tə ə pɹətɛkʃən ðət wɪl skɝdʒ ʌs. ðə laɪt hɛlp əs ɔl." ði æmɪɝlɪn ʃʊk hɝsɛlf əz ɪf tə θɹoʊ ɔf əɹ oʊn wɝdz. hɝ feɪs wɑz sɛt, əz ðoʊ bɹeɪsɪŋ fəɹ ə bloʊ. "ju kəd nɛvɝ haɪd wʌt jə wɝ θɪŋkɪŋ fɹəm mi əz jə də fɹəm ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls, mɔɪɹeɪn. juv mɔɹ tə tɛl mi, ən nʌθɪŋ ɡʊd."

" 'For he shall come like the breaking dawn, and shatter the world again with his coming, and make it anew.' Either we go naked in the storm, or cling to a protection that will scourge us. The Light help us all." The Amyrlin shook herself as if to throw off her own words. Her face was set, as though bracing for a blow. "You could never hide what you were thinking from me as you do from everyone else, Moiraine. You have more to tell me, and nothing good."

fəɹ ænsɝ mɔɪɹeɪn tʊk ðə lɛðɝ paʊtʃ fɹəm əɹ bɛlt ən ʌpɛndəɾ ɪt, spɪlɪŋ ðə kɑntɛns ɑn ðə teɪbəl. ɪɾ əpɪɹd tə bi oʊnli ə hip ə fɹæɡməntɪd pɑɾɝi, ʃaɪni blæk ən waɪt.

For answer Moiraine took the leather pouch from her belt and upended it, spilling the contents on the table. It appeared to be only a heap of fragmented pottery, shiny black and white.

ði æmɪɝlɪn sit tʌtʃt wʌn bɪt kjʊɹiəsli, ən əɹ bɹɛθ kɑt. "kwəndɪlɝ."

The Amyrlin Seat touched one bit curiously, and her breath caught. "Cuendillar."

"hɑɹtstoʊn," mɔɪɹeɪn əɡɹid. ðə meɪkɪŋ ə kwəndɪlɝ hæd bɪn lɔst ət ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld, bʌt wʌt hæd bɪn meɪɾ ə hɑɹtstoʊn hæd sɝvaɪv ðə kæɾəklɪsəm. ivən ðoʊz ɑbʒɛkts swɑloʊd baɪ ði ɝθ əɹ sʌŋk ɪn ðə si hæd sɝvaɪvd; ðeɪ mʌs hæv. noʊ noʊn fɔɹs kəd bɹeɪk kwəndɪlɝ wʌns ɪt wɑz kəmplit; ivən ðə wʌn paʊɝ dɝɛktəɾ əɡɛns hɑɹtstoʊn oʊnli meɪɾ ɪt stʃɹɔŋɝ. ɪksɛp ðət səm paʊɝ hæd bɹoʊkən ðɪs.

"Heartstone," Moiraine agreed. The making of cuendillar had been lost at the Breaking of the World, but what had been made of heartstone had survived the cataclysm. Even those objects swallowed by the earth or sunk in the sea had survived; they must have. No known force could break cuendillar once it was complete; even the One Power directed against heartstone only made it stronger. Except that some power had broken this.

ði æmɪɝlɪn heɪstəli əsɛmbəl ðə pisəz. wʌt ðeɪ fɔɹmd wɑz ə dɪsk ðə saɪz ʌv ə mænz hænd, hæf blækɝ ðən pɪtʃ ən hæf waɪɾɝ ðən snoʊ, ðə kʌlɝz miɾɪŋ əlɔŋ ə sɪnwəs laɪn, ənfeɪɾɪd baɪ eɪdʒ. ði eɪntʃən sɪmbəl ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ, bɪfɔɹ ðə wɝld wɑz bɹoʊkən, wən mɛn ən wɪmən wildɪd ðə paʊɝ təɡɛðɝ. hæf ʌv ɪt wɑz naʊ kɔl ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn; ði ʌðɝ hæf wɑz skɹɔld ɑn dɔɹz, ðə dʒɹæɡənz fæŋ, tə əkjuz ðoʊz wɪðɪn ʌv ivəl. oʊnli sɛvən laɪk ɪt hæd bɪn meɪd; ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛvɝ meɪɾ ə hɑɹtstoʊn wɑz ɹəkɔɹɾəd ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ən ðoʊz sɛvən wɝ ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ əbʌv ɔl. sɪuən sɑntʃ stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪɾ əz ʃi wəɾ əv əɾ ə vaɪpɝ ɑn əɹ pɪloʊ.

The Amyrlin hastily assembled the pieces. What they formed was a disk the size of a man's hand, half blacker than pitch and half whiter than snow, the colors meeting along a sinuous line, unfaded by age. The ancient symbol of Aes Sedai, before the world was broken, when men and women wielded the Power together. Half of it was now called the Flame of Tar Valon; the other half was scrawled on doors, the Dragon's Fang, to accuse those within of evil. Only seven like it had been made; everything ever made of heartstone was recorded in the White Tower, and those seven were remembered above all. Siuan Sanche stared at it as she would have at a viper on her pillow.

"wʌn ə ðə silz ɑn ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən," ʃi sɛd faɪnəli, ɹɪlʌktənli. ɪt wɑz ðoʊz sɛvən silz oʊvɝ wɪtʃ ði æmɪɝlɪn sit wɑz səpoʊz tə bi wɑtʃɝ. ðə sikɹət hɪɾən fɹəm ðə wɝld, ɪf ðə wɝld ɛvɝ θɔɾ ʌv ɪt, wɑz ðət noʊ æmɪɝlɪn sit hæd noʊn wɛɹ ɛni ʌv ðə silz wɝ sɪns ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz.

"One of the seals on the Dark One's prison," she said finally, reluctantly. It was those seven seals over which the Amyrlin Seat was supposed to be Watcher. The secret hidden from the world, if the world ever thought of it, was that no Amyrlin Seat had known where any of the seals were since the Trolloc Wars.
