"wi noʊ ðə dɑɹk wʌn ɪz stɝɪŋ, sɪuən. wi noʊ hɪz pɹɪzən kænɑt steɪ sil fɝɛvɝ. hjumən wɝk kən nɛvɝ mætʃ ðə kɹieɪɾɝz. wi nu hiz tʌtʃt ðə wɝld əɡɛn, ivən ɪf, θæŋk ðə laɪt, oʊnli ɪndɝɛkli. dɑɹkfɹɛnz mʌltəplaɪ, ən wʌt wi kɔld ivəl bʌt tɛn jɪɹz əɡoʊ simz ɔlmoʊs kəpɹis kəmpɛɹd wɪð wʌt naʊ ɪz dʌn ɛvɹi deɪ."

"We know the Dark One is stirring, Siuan. We know his prison cannot stay sealed forever. Human work can never match the Creator's. We knew he has touched the world again, even if, thank the Light, only indirectly. Darkfriends multiply, and what we called evil but ten years ago seems almost caprice compared with what now is done every day."

"ɪf ðə silz ɑɹ ɔlɹɛɾi bɹeɪkɪŋ. . . . wi meɪ hæv noʊ taɪm əɾ ɔl."

"If the seals are already breaking. . . . We may have no time at all."

"lɪɾəl ɪnʌf. bʌt ðət lɪɾəl meɪ bi ɪnʌf. ɪɾəl əv tə bi."

"Little enough. But that little may be enough. It will have to be."

ði æmɪɝlɪn tʌtʃt ðə fɹæktʃɝd sil, ən əɹ vɔɪs ɡɹu taɪt, əz ɪf ʃi wɝ fɔɹsɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə spik. "aɪ sɔ ðə bɔɪ, jə noʊ, ɪn ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɛlkəm. ɪts wʌn ə maɪ tæləns, siɪŋ tɑvɝən. ə ɹɛɹ tælən ðiz deɪz, ivən mɔɹ ɹɛɹ ðən tɑvɝən, ən sɝɾənli nɑɾ ə mʌtʃ juz. ə tɔl bɔɪ, ə fɛɹli hænsəm jʌŋ mæn. nɑt mʌtʃ dɪfɹən fɹəm ɛni jʌŋ mæn jə maɪt si ɪn ɛni taʊn." ʃi pɔz tə dʒɹɔ bɹɛθ. "mɔɪɹeɪn, hi bleɪz laɪk ðə sʌn. aɪv sɛldəm bɪn əfɹeɪɾ ɪn maɪ laɪf, bʌt ðə saɪɾ ə hɪm meɪd mi əfɹeɪd ɹaɪt daʊn tə maɪ toʊz. aɪ wɑntəd tə kaʊɝ, tə haʊl. aɪ kəd bɛɹli spik. eɪɡəlmɝ θɔɾ aɪ wɑz æŋɡɹi wɪð hɪm, aɪ sɛd soʊ lɪɾəl. ðət jʌŋ mæn . . . hiz ðə wʌn wɪv sɔt ðiz twɛnti jɪɹz."

The Amyrlin touched the fractured seal, and her voice grew tight, as if she were forcing herself to speak. "I saw the boy, you know, in the courtyard during the Welcome. It is one of my Talents, seeing ta'veren. A rare Talent these days, even more rare than ta'veren, and certainly not of much use. A tall boy, a fairly handsome young man. Not much different from any young man you might see in any town." She paused to draw breath. "Moiraine, he blazed like the sun. I've seldom been afraid in my life, but the sight of him made me afraid right down to my toes. I wanted to cower, to howl. I could barely speak. Agelmar thought I was angry with him, I said so little. That young man . . . he's the one we have sought these twenty years."

ðəɹ wɑz ə hɪn ə kwɛstʃən ɪn əɹ vɔɪs. mɔɪɹeɪn ænsɝɾ ɪt. "hi ɪz."

There was a hint of question in her voice. Moiraine answered it. "He is."

"ɑɹ jə sɝɾən? kən i . . . ? kən i . . . tʃænəl ðə wʌn paʊɝ?"

"Are you certain? Can he . . . ? Can he . . . channel the One Power?"

hɝ maʊθ stʃɹeɪn ɝaʊn ðə wɝdz, ən mɔɪɹeɪn fɛl ðə tɛnʃən, tu, ə twɪstɪŋ ɪnsaɪd, ə koʊl klʌtʃɪŋ əɾ əɹ hɑɹt. ʃi kɛpt əɹ feɪs smuð, ðoʊ. "hi kæn." ə mæn wildɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ðət wɑz ə θɪŋ noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd kɑntəmpleɪt wɪθaʊt fɪɹ. ɪt wɑz ə θɪŋ ðə hoʊl wɝl fɪɹd. ən əl lus ɪɾ ɑn ðə wɝld. "ɹæn ælθɹ wɪl stæn bɪfɔɹ ðə wɝld əz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn."

Her mouth strained around the words, and Moiraine felt the tension, too, a twisting inside, a cold clutching at her heart. She kept her face smooth, though. "He can." A man wielding the One Power. That was a thing no Aes Sedai could contemplate without fear. It was a thing the whole world feared. And I will loose it on the world. "Rand al'Thor will stand before the world as the Dragon Reborn."

ði æmɪɝlɪn ʃʌɾɝəd. "ɹæn ælθɹ. ɪt dʌz nɑt saʊn laɪk ə neɪm tə ɪnspaɪɹ fɪɹ ən sɛt ðə wɝld ɑn faɪɝ." ʃi ɡeɪv ənʌðɝ ʃɪvɝ ən ɹʌbd əɹ ɑɹmz bɹɪskli, bʌɾ əɹ aɪz sʌɾənli ʃoʊn wɪð ə pɝpəsfəl laɪt. "ɪf hiz ðə wʌn, ðən wi tʃɹuli meɪ hæv taɪm ɪnʌf. bʌɾ ɪz i seɪf hɪɹ? aɪ hæv tu ɹɛd sɪstɝz wɪð mi, ən aɪ kən noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ænsɝ fəɹ ɡɹin əɹ jɛloʊ, iðɝ. ðə laɪt kənsum mi, aɪ kæn ænsɝ fəɹ ɛni ʌv ðɛm, nɑt wɪð ðɪs. ivən vɛɹɪn ən sɹəfɛl wəd lip ɑn ɪm ðə weɪ ðeɪ wəɾ ə skɑɹləɾ æɾɝ ɪn ə nɝsɝi."

The Amyrlin shuddered. "Rand al'Thor. It does not sound like a name to inspire fear and set the world on fire." She gave another shiver and rubbed her arms briskly, but her eyes suddenly shone with a purposeful light. "If he is the one, then we truly may have time enough. But is he safe here? I have two Red sisters with me, and I can no longer answer for Green or Yellow, either. The Light consume me, I can't answer for any of them, not with this. Even Verin and Serafelle would leap on him the way they would a scarlet adder in a nursery."

"hi ɪz seɪf, fəɹ ðə moʊmənt."

"He is safe, for the moment."

ði æmɪɝlɪn weɪɾəd fəɹ əɹ tə seɪ mɔɹ. ðə saɪləns stʃɹɛtʃt, əntɪl ɪt wɑz pleɪn ʃi wəd nɑt. faɪnəli ði æmɪɝlɪn sɛd, "ju seɪ əɹ oʊl plæn ɪz jusləs. wʌt dʒju sədʒɛs naʊ?"

The Amyrlin waited for her to say more. The silence stretched, until it was plain she would not. Finally the Amyrlin said, "You say our old plan is useless. What do you suggest now?"

"aɪ hæv pɝpəsli lɛɾ ɪm θɪŋk aɪ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ əv ɛni ɪntʃɹəst ɪn hɪm, ðəɾ i meɪ ɡoʊ wɛɹ i plizɪz fəɹ ɔl ə mi." ʃi ɹeɪzd əɹ hænz əz ði æmɪɝlɪn oʊpən əɹ maʊð. "ɪt wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi, sɪuən. ɹænd ælθɹ wɑz ɹeɪzd ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, wɛɹ meɪnɛðɝənz stʌbɝn blʌd floʊz ɪn ɛvɹi veɪn, ən ɪz oʊn blʌɾ ɪz laɪk ɹɑk bɪsaɪd kleɪ kəmpɛɹd tə meɪnɛðɝənz. hi mʌs bi hændəl dʒɛnli, əɹ hɪl boʊlt ɪn ɛni dɝɛkʃən bʌt ðə wʌn wi wɑnt."

"I have purposely let him think I no longer have any interest in him, that he may go where he pleases for all of me." She raised her hands as the Amyrlin opened her mouth. "It was necessary, Siuan. Rand al'Thor was raised in the Two Rivers, where Manetheren's stubborn blood flows in every vein, and his own blood is like rock beside clay compared to Manetheren's. He must be handled gently, or he will bolt in any direction but the one we want."

"ðɛn wɪl hændəl ɪm laɪk ə nubɔɹn beɪb. wɪl ɹæp ɪm ɪn swɑɾəlɪŋ kloʊðz ən pleɪ wɪð ɪz toʊz, ɪf ðæts wʌt jə θɪŋk wi nid. bʌt tə wʌɾ ɪmiɾiət pɝpəs?"

"Then we'll handle him like a newborn babe. We'll wrap him in swaddling clothes and play with his toes, if that's what you think we need. But to what immediate purpose?"

"hɪz tu fɹɛnz, meɪtʃɹim kɔθən ən pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə, ɑɹ ɹaɪp tə si ðə wɝl bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ sɪŋk bæk ɪndə ði əbskjʊɹəɾi ʌv ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. ɪf ðeɪ kən sɪŋk bæk; ðeɪ ɑɹ tɑvɝən, tu, ɪf lɛsɝ ðən hi. əl ɪndus əm tə kæɹi ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ tə ɪljən." ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, fɹaʊnɪŋ. "ðɛɹ ɪz . . . ə pɹɑbləm wɪð mæt. hi kæɹiz ə dæɡɝ fɹəm ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ."

"His two friends, Matrim Cauthon and Perrin Aybara, are ripe to see the world before they sink back into the obscurity of the Two Rivers. If they can sink back; they are ta'veren, too, if lesser than he. I will induce them to carry the Horn of Valere to Illian." She hesitated, frowning. "There is . . . a problem with Mat. He carries a dagger from Shadar Logoth."

"ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ! laɪt, waɪ dɪd jə ɛvɝ lɛɾ əm ɡɛt nɪɹ ðət pleɪs. ɛvɹi stoʊn ʌv ɪts teɪntɪd. ðəɹ ɪzən ə pɛbəl seɪf tə kæɹi əweɪ. laɪt hɛlp ʌs, ɪf mɔɹɾɪθ tʌtʃt ðə bɔɪ. . . ." ði æmɪɝlɪn saʊndəɾ əz ðoʊ ʃi wɝ stʃɹæŋɡəlɪŋ. "ɪf ðət hæpənd, ðə wɝld wəd bi dumd."

"Shadar Logoth! Light, why did you ever let them get near that place. Every stone of it is tainted. There isn't a pebble safe to carry away. Light help us, if Mordeth touched the boy. . . ." The Amyrlin sounded as though she were strangling. "If that happened, the world would be doomed."

"bʌɾ ɪt dɪd nɑt, sɪuən. wi də wʌt wi mʌs fɹəm nəsɛsəɾi, ən ɪt wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi. aɪ hæv dʌn ɪnʌf soʊ ðət mæt wɪl nɑɾ ɪnfɛkt ʌðɝz, bʌɾ i hæd ðə dæɡɝ tu lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ aɪ nu. ðə lɪŋk ɪz stɪl ðɛɹ. aɪ hæd θɔɾ aɪ mʌs teɪk ɪm tə tɑɹ vəlɑn tə kjʊɹ ɪt, bʌt wɪð soʊ mɛni sɪstɝz pɹɛzənt, ɪt maɪt bi dʌn hɪɹ. soʊ lɔŋ əz ðəɹ ɑɹ ə fju jə kən tʃɹʌs nɑt tə si dɑɹkfɹɛnz wɛɹ ðəɹ ɑɹ nʌn. jə ən aɪ ən tu ʌðɝz wɪl səfaɪs, juzɪŋ maɪ æŋɡɹil."

"But it did not, Siuan. We do what we must from necessity, and it was necessary. I have done enough so that Mat will not infect others, but he had the dagger too long before I knew. The link is still there. I had thought I must take him to Tar Valon to cure it, but with so many sisters present, it might be done here. So long as there are a few you can trust not to see Darkfriends where there are none. You and I and two others will suffice, using my angreal."

"lin wɪl də fəɹ wʌn, ən aɪ kən faɪn ənʌðɝ." sʌɾənli ði æmɪɝlɪn sit ɡeɪv ə ɹaɪ ɡɹɪn. "ðə hɔl wɑns ðəɾ æŋɡɹil bæk, mɔɪɹeɪn. ðəɹ ɑɹ nɑt vɛɹi mɛni ʌv əm lɛft, ən jə ɑɹ naʊ kənsɪɾɝd . . . ʌnɹɪlaɪəbəl."

"Leane will do for one, and I can find another." Suddenly the Amyrlin Seat gave a wry grin. "The Hall wants that angreal back, Moiraine. There are not very many of them left, and you are now considered . . . unreliable."

mɔɪɹeɪn smaɪld, bʌɾ ɪt dɪd nɑt tʌtʃ əɹ aɪz. "ðeɪ wɪl θɪŋk wɝs ə mi bɪfɔɹ aɪm dʌn. mæt wɪl lip ət ðə tʃæns tə bi soʊ bɪɡ ə pɑɹɾ ə ðə lɛdʒən ə ðə hɔɹn, ən pɛɹɪn ʃəd nɑt bi hɑɹd tə kənvɪns. hi nidz sʌmθɪŋ tə teɪk ɪz maɪn ɔf ɪz oʊn tʃɹʌbəlz. ɹænd noʊz wʌt hiz - səm ʌv ɪt, ət list; ə lɪɾəl - ən hiz əfɹeɪɾ ʌv ɪt, nætʃɹəli. hi wɑns tə ɡoʊ ɔf sʌmwɛɹ əloʊn, wɛɹ i kænɑt hɝɾ ɛniwʌn. hi sɛz hɪl nɛvɝ wil ðə paʊɝ əɡɛn, bʌɾ i fɪɹz nɑt biɪŋ eɪbəl tə stɑp ɪt."

Moiraine smiled, but it did not touch her eyes. "They will think worse of me before I am done. Mat will leap at the chance to be so big a part of the legend of the Horn, and Perrin should not be hard to convince. He needs something to take his mind off his own troubles. Rand knows what he is - some of it, at least; a little - and he is afraid of it, naturally. He wants to go off somewhere alone, where he cannot hurt anyone. He says he will never wield the Power again, but he fears not being able to stop it."

"æz wɛl i maɪt. iziɝ tə ɡɪv ʌp dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ wɔɾɝ."

"As well he might. Easier to give up drinking water."

"ɪɡzækli. ən i wɑns tə bi fɹi fɹəm ɛɛs sədaɪ." mɔɪɹeɪn ɡeɪv ə smɔl, mɝθləs smaɪl. "ɔfɝd ðə tʃæns tə liv ɛɛs sədaɪ bɪhaɪn ən stɪl steɪ wɪð ɪz fɹɛnz ə waɪl lɔŋɡɝ, hi ʃəd bi əz iɡɝ əz mæt."

"Exactly. And he wants to be free from Aes Sedai." Moiraine gave a small, mirthless smile. "Offered the chance to leave Aes Sedai behind and still stay with his friends a while longer, he should be as eager as Mat."

"bʌt haʊ ɪz i livɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ bɪhaɪnd? ʃʊɹli jə mʌs tʃɹævəl wɪð hɪm. wi kæn luz ɪm naʊ, mɔɪɹeɪn."

"But how is he leaving Aes Sedai behind? Surely you must travel with him. We can't lose him now, Moiraine."

"aɪ kænɑt tʃɹævəl wɪð hɪm." ɪts ə lɔŋ weɪ fɹəm fæl dæɹə tə ɪljən, bʌt hiz tʃɹævəld ɔlmoʊst əz fɑɹ ɔlɹɛɾi. "hi mʌs bi lɛɾ ɔf ðə liʃ fəɹ ə taɪm. ðəɹ ɪz noʊ hɛlp fəɹ ɪt. aɪ hæv hæɾ ɔl ə ðɛɹ oʊl kloʊðz bɝnd. ðəɹ əz bɪn tu mʌtʃ ɑpɝtunəɾi fəɹ səm ʃɹɛɾ ʌv wʌt ðeɪ wɝ wɛɹɪŋ tə hæv fɔlən ɪndə ðə ɹɔŋ hænz. əl klɛnz əm bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ liv; ðəl nɑɾ ivən ɹilaɪz ɪts bɪn dʌn. ðəɹ wɪl bi noʊ tʃæns ðeɪ kən bi tʃɹæk ðət weɪ, ən ði oʊnli ʌðɝ θɹɛɾ ə ðət kaɪn ɪz lɑkt əweɪ hɪɹ ɪn ðə dʌnʒən." ði æmɪɝlɪn, mɪdweɪ ɪn nɑɾɪŋ əpɹuvəl, ɡeɪv əɹ ə kwɛstʃənɪŋ lʊk, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt pɔz. "ðeɪ wɪl tʃɹævəl əz seɪfli əz aɪ kən mænədʒ, sɪuən. ən wən ɹænd nidz mi ɪn ɪljən, əl bi ðɛɹ, ən əl si ðəɾ ɪts i hu pɹizɛns ðə hɔɹn tə ðə kaʊnsəl ə naɪn ən ði əsɛmblədʒ. əl si tə ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪn ɪljən. sɪuən, ði ɪliɑnɝz wəd fɑloʊ ðə dʒɹæɡən, əɹ bælzəmən hɪmsɛlf, ɪf i keɪm bɛɹɪŋ ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ, ən soʊ wɪl ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ pɑɹɾ ə ðoʊz ɡæðɝd fəɹ ðə hʌnt. ðə tʃɹu dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɪl nɑt nid tə ɡæðɝ ə fɑloʊɪŋ bɪfɔɹ neɪʃənz muv əɡɛns hɪm. hɪl bɪɡɪn wɪð ə neɪʃən ɝaʊn ɪm ən ən ɑɹmi əɾ ɪz bæk."

"I cannot travel with him." It is a long way from Fal Dara to Illian, but he has traveled almost as far already. "He must be let off the leash for a time. There is no help for it. I have had all of their old clothes burned. There has been too much opportunity for some shred of what they were wearing to have fallen into the wrong hands. I will cleanse them before they leave; they will not even realize it has been done. There will be no chance they can be tracked that way, and the only other threat of that kind is locked away here in the dungeon." The Amyrlin, midway in nodding approval, gave her a questioning look, but she did not pause. "They will travel as safely as I can manage, Siuan. And when Rand needs me in Illian, I will be there, and I will see that it is he who presents the Horn to the Council of Nine and the Assemblage. I will see to everything in Illian. Siuan, the Illianers would follow the Dragon, or Ba'alzamon himself, if he came bearing the Horn of Valere, and so will the greater part of those gathered for the Hunt. The true Dragon Reborn will not need to gather a following before nations move against him. He will begin with a nation around him and an army at his back."

ði æmɪɝlɪn dʒɹɑp bæk ɪndə hɝ tʃɛɹ, bʌɾ ɪmiɾiətli lin fɔɹwɝd. ʃi sim kɑt bɪtwin wɪɹinəs ən hoʊp. "bʌt wɪl i pɹoʊkleɪm hɪmsɛlf? ɪf hiz əfɹeɪd. . . . ðə laɪt noʊz i ʃəd bi, mɔɪɹeɪn, bʌt mɛn u neɪm ðɛmsɛlvz əz ðə dʒɹæɡən wɑn ðə paʊɝ. ɪf i dʌz nɑt. . . ."

The Amyrlin dropped back into her chair, but immediately leaned forward. She seemed caught between weariness and hope. "But will he proclaim himself? If he's afraid. . . . The Light knows he should be, Moiraine, but men who name themselves as the Dragon want the power. If he does not. . . ."

"aɪ hæv ðə minz tə si hɪm neɪm dʒɹæɡən wɛðɝ i wɪlz ɪɾ əɹ nɑt. ən ivən ɪf aɪ sʌmhaʊ feɪl, ðə pæɾɝn ɪtsɛlf wɪl si hɪm neɪm dʒɹæɡən wɛðɝ i wɪlz ɪɾ əɹ nɑt. ɹɪmɛmbɝ, hiz tɑvɝən, sɪuən. hiz noʊ mɔɹ kəntʃɹoʊl oʊvɝ ɪz feɪt ðən ə kændəl wɪk əz oʊvɝ ðə fleɪm."

"I have the means to see him named Dragon whether he wills it or not. And even if I somehow fail, the Pattern itself will see him named Dragon whether he wills it or not. Remember, he is ta'veren, Siuan. He has no more control over his fate than a candle wick has over the flame."

ði æmɪɝlɪn saɪd. "ɪts ɹɪski, mɔɪɹeɪn. ɹɪski. bʌt maɪ fɑðɝ juz tə seɪ, 'ɡɝl, ɪf jə woʊn teɪk ə tʃæns, jəl nɛvɝ wɪn ə kɑpɝ.' wɪv plænz tə meɪk. sɪt daʊn; ðɪs woʊn bi dʌn kwɪkli. əl sɛn fəɹ waɪn ən tʃiz."

The Amyrlin sighed. "It's risky, Moiraine. Risky. But my father used to say, 'Girl, if you won't take a chance, you'll never win a copper.' We have plans to make. Sit down; this won't be done quickly. I will send for wine and cheese."

mɔɪɹeɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "wi hæv bɪn klɑzəɾɪd əloʊn tu lɔŋ ɔlɹɛɾi. ɪf ɛni dɪd tʃɹaɪ lɪsnɪŋ ən faʊn jəɹ wɔɹɾɪŋ, ðəl bi wʌndɝɪŋ ɔlɹɛɾi. ɪts nɑt wɝθ ðə ɹɪsk. wi kən kəntʃɹaɪv ənʌðɝ miɾɪŋ təmɑɹoʊ." bɪsaɪdz, maɪ dɪɹəs fɹɛnd, aɪ kænɑt tɛl jə ɛvɹiθɪŋ, ən aɪ kænɑt ɹɪsk lɛɾɪŋ jə noʊ aɪm hoʊldɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ bæk.

Moiraine shook her head. "We have been closeted alone too long already. If any did try listening and found your Warding, they will be wondering already. It is not worth the risk. We can contrive another meeting tomorrow." Besides, my dearest friend, I cannot tell you everything, and I cannot risk letting you know I am holding anything back.

"aɪ səpoʊz jə ɑɹ ɹaɪt. bʌt fɝs θɪŋ ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ. ðɛɹz soʊ mʌtʃ aɪ hæv tə noʊ."

"I suppose you are right. But first thing in the morning. There's so much I have to know."

"ðə mɔɹnɪŋ," mɔɪɹeɪn əɡɹid. ði æmɪɝlɪn ɹoʊz, ən ðeɪ hʌɡd əɡɛn. "ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ əl tɛl jə ɛvɹiθɪŋ jə nid tə noʊ."

"The morning," Moiraine agreed. The Amyrlin rose, and they hugged again. "In the morning I will tell you everything you need to know."

lin ɡeɪv mɔɪɹeɪn ə ʃɑɹp lʊk wən ʃi keɪm aʊɾ ɪndə ði æntəɹum, ðən dɑɹɾɪd ɪndə ði æmɪɝlɪnz tʃeɪmbɝ. mɔɪɹeɪn tʃɹaɪd tə pʊɾ ɑn ə tʃeɪsən feɪs, əz ɪf ʃi hæɾ ɛndʒjʊɹd wʌn ə ði æmɪɝlɪnz ɪnfəməs ʌpbɹeɪɾɪŋz - moʊst wɪmən, haʊɛvɝ stʃɹɔŋ-wɪld, ɹɪtɝn fɹəm ðoʊz bɪɡ-aɪɾ ən wik-nid - bʌt ði ɪkspɹɛʃən wɑz fɔɹən tə hɝ. ʃi lʊk mɔɹ æŋɡɹi ðən ɛniθɪŋ ɛls, wɪtʃ sɝv mʌtʃ ðə seɪm pɝpəs. ʃi wɑz oʊnli veɪɡli əwɛɹ ə ði ʌðɝ wɪmən ɪn ði aʊɾɝ ɹum; ʃi θɔt səm hæd ɡɔn ən ʌðɝz kʌm sɪns ʃi wɛn ɪn, bʌt ʃi bɛɹli lʊkt ət ðɛm. ði aʊɝ wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ leɪt, ən ðəɹ wɑz mʌtʃ tə bi dʌn bɪfɔɹ ðə mɔɹnɪŋ keɪm. mʌtʃ, bɪfɔɹ ʃi spoʊk tə ði æmɪɝlɪn siɾ əɡɛn.

Leane gave Moiraine a sharp look when she came out into the anteroom, then darted into the Amyrlin's chamber. Moiraine tried to put on a chastened face, as if she had endured one of the Amyrlin's infamous upbraidings - most women, however strong-willed, returned from those big-eyed and weak-kneed - but the expression was foreign to her. She looked more angry than anything else, which served much the same purpose. She was only vaguely aware of the other women in the outer room; she thought some had gone and others come since she went in, but she barely looked at them. The hour was growing late, and there was much to be done before the morning came. Much, before she spoke to the Amyrlin Seat again.

kwɪkənɪŋ əɹ stɛp, ʃi muv dipɝ ɪndə ðə kip.

Quickening her step, she moved deeper into the keep.

ðə kɑləm wʊɾə meɪɾ ən ɪmpɹɛsɪv saɪɾ ʌndɝ ðə wæksɪŋ mun, muvɪŋ θɹu ðə tæɹɑbən naɪt tə ðə dʒæŋɡəl ə hɑɹnəs, hæd ðəɹ bɪn ɛniwʌn tə si ɪt. ə fʊl tu θaʊzən tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt, wɛl maʊntəd, ɪn waɪt tɑbɝdz ən kloʊks, ɑɹmɝ bɝnɪʃt, wɪð ðɛɹ tʃɹeɪn ə səplaɪ wæɡənz, ən fɛɹiɝz, ən ɡɹumz wɪð ðə stʃɹɪŋz ə ɹimaʊns. ðəɹ wɝ vɪlədʒəz ɪn ðɪs spɑɹsli fɔɹəstəd kʌntʃɹi, bʌt ðeɪ hæd lɛft ɹoʊdz bɪhaɪnd, ən steɪd klɪɹ ʌv ivən fɑɹmɝz' kɹɔfs. ðeɪ wɝ tə mit . . . sʌmwʌn . . . əɾ ə flaɪspɛk vɪlədʒ nɪɹ ðə nɔɹðɝn bɔɹɾɝ ə tæɹɑbən, ət ði ɛdʒ ʌv ɑlməθ pleɪn.

The column would have made an impressive sight under the waxing moon, moving through the Tarabon night to the jangle of harness, had there been anyone to see it. A full two thousand Children of the Light, well mounted, in white tabards and cloaks, armor burnished, with their train of supply wagons, and farriers, and grooms with the strings of remounts. There were villages in this sparsely forested country, but they had left roads behind, and stayed clear of even farmers' crofts. They were to meet . . . someone . . . at a flyspeck village near the northern border of Tarabon, at the edge of Almoth Plain.

dʒɛəfɹæm bɔɹnhəld, ɹaɪɾɪŋ ət ðə hɛɾ ə hɪz mɛn, wʌndɝd wʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɔl əbaʊt. hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd tu wɛl ɪz ɪntɝvju wɪð peɪdʒɹən naɪl, lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt, ɪn æmədɔɹ, bʌɾ i hæd lɝn lɪɾəl ðɛɹ.

Geofram Bornhald, riding at the head of his men, wondered what it was all about. He remembered too well his interview with Pedron Niall, Lord Captain Commander of the Children of the Light, in Amador, but he had learned little there.

"wi ɑɹ əloʊn, dʒɛəfɹæm," ðə waɪt-hɛɹd mæn hæd sɛd. hɪz vɔɪs wɑz θɪn ən ɹiɾi wɪð eɪdʒ. "aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɡɪvɪŋ jə ði oʊθ . . . wʌt . . . θɝɾi-sɪks jɪɹz əɡoʊ, ɪt mʌs bi, naʊ."

"We are alone, Geofram," the white-haired man had said. His voice was thin and reedy with age. "I remember giving you the oath . . . what . . . thirty-six years ago, it must be, now."

bɔɹnhəl stʃɹeɪɾənd. "maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ, meɪ aɪ æsk waɪ aɪ wɑz kɔl bæk fɹəm keɪɛmlɪn, ən wɪð sətʃ ɝdʒənsi? ə pʊʃ, ən mɔɹɡeɪs kəd bi tɑpəld. ðəɹ ɑɹ haʊzɪz ɪn ændɝ ðət si dilɪŋ wɪð tɑɹ vəlɑn əz wi du, ən ðeɪ wɝ ɹɛɾi tə leɪ kleɪm tə ðə θɹoʊn. aɪ lɛft imən vɑldə ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ, bʌɾ i simd ɪntɛn ɑn fɑloʊɪŋ ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn. aɪ wəd nɑt bi sɝpɹaɪz tə lɝn ðə mæn əz kɪdnæp ðə ɡɝl, əɹ ivən ətæk tɑɹ vəlɑn." ən deɪn, bɔɹnhəlz sʌn, hæɾ ɝaɪv dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ bɔɹnhəld wɑz ɹɪkɔld. deɪn wɑz fʊl ə zil. tu mʌtʃ zil, səmtaɪmz. ɪnʌf tə fɔl ɪn blaɪnli wɪð wʌtɛvɝ vɑldə pɹəpoʊzd.

Bornhald straightened. "My Lord Captain Commander, may I ask why I was called back from Caemlyn, and with such urgency? A push, and Morgase could be toppled. There are Houses in Andor that see dealing with Tar Valon as we do, and they were ready to lay claim to the throne. I left Eamon Valda in charge, but he seemed intent on following the Daughter-Heir to Tar Valon. I would not be surprised to learn the man has kidnapped the girl, or even attacked Tar Valon." And Dain, Bornhald's son, had arrived just before Bornhald was recalled. Dain was full of zeal. Too much zeal, sometimes. Enough to fall in blindly with whatever Valda proposed.

"vɑldə wɔks ɪn ðə laɪt, dʒɛəfɹæm. bʌt jə ɑɹ ðə bɛs bæɾəl kəmændɝ əmʌŋ ðə tʃɪlʒɹən. jəl əsɛmbəl ə fʊl lidʒən, ðə bɛs mɛn jə kən faɪnd, ən teɪk əm ɪndə tæɹɑbən, əvɔɪɾɪŋ ɛni aɪz ətætʃt tə ə tʌŋ ðət meɪ spik. ɛni sətʃ tʌŋ mʌs bi saɪlənst, ɪf ði aɪz si."

"Valda walks in the Light, Geofram. But you are the best battle commander among the Children. You will assemble a full legion, the best men you can find, and take them into Tarabon, avoiding any eyes attached to a tongue that may speak. Any such tongue must be silenced, if the eyes see."

bɔɹnhəl hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. fɪfti tʃɪlʒɹən təɡɛðɝ, əɹ ivən ə hʌnʒɹəd, kəɾ ɛntɝ ɛni lænd wɪθaʊt kwɛstʃən, ət list wɪθaʊɾ oʊpən kwɛstʃən, bʌɾ ən ɪntaɪɝ lidʒən. . . . "ɪz ɪt wɔɹ, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ? ðəɹ ɪz tɔk ɪn ðə stʃɹits. waɪld ɹumɝz, meɪnli, əbaʊɾ ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz ɑɹmiz kʌm bæk." ði oʊl mæn dɪd nɑt spik. "ðə kɪŋ. . . ."

Bornhald hesitated. Fifty Children together, or even a hundred, could enter any land without question, at least without open question, but an entire legion. . . . "Is it war, my Lord Captain Commander? There is talk in the streets. Wild rumors, mainly, about Artur Hawkwing's armies come back." The old man did not speak. "The King. . . ."

"dʌz nɑt kəmæn ðə tʃɪlʒɹən, lɔɹd kæptən bɔɹnhəld." fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm ðəɹ wɑz ə snæp ɪn ðə lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝz vɔɪs. "aɪ du. lɛt ðə kɪŋ sɪɾ ɪn ɪz pæləs ən də wʌɾ i dʌz bɛst. nʌθɪŋ. jəl bi mɛɾ əɾ ə vɪlədʒ kɔld ælkɹunə, ən ðəɹ jəl ɹəsiv jəɹ faɪnəl ɔɹɾɝz. aɪ ɪkspɛk jəɹ lidʒən tə ɹaɪɾ ɪn θɹi deɪz. naʊ ɡoʊ, dʒɛəfɹæm. juv wɝk tə du."

"Does not command the Children, Lord Captain Bornhald." For the first time there was a snap in the Lord Captain Commander's voice. "I do. Let the King sit in his palace and do what he does best. Nothing. You will be met at a village called Alcruna, and there you will receive your final orders. I expect your legion to ride in three days. Now go, Geofram. You have work to do."

bɔɹnhəl fɹaʊnd. "pɑɹɾən, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ, bʌɾ u wɪl mit mi? waɪ æm aɪ ɹɪskɪŋ wɔɹ wɪð tæɹɑbən?"

Bornhald frowned. "Pardon, my Lord Captain Commander, but who will meet me? Why am I risking war with Tarabon?"

"ju wɪl bi toʊld wʌt jə mʌs noʊ wən jə ɹitʃ ælkɹunə." ðə lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ sʌɾənli lʊk mɔɹ ðən ɪz eɪdʒ. æbsənli hi plʌkt əɾ ɪz waɪt tunɪk, wɪð ðə ɡoʊldən sʌnbɝst ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən lɑɹdʒ ɑn ðə tʃɛst. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ fɔɹsɪz ət wɝk bɪɑnd wʌt jə noʊ, dʒɛəfɹæm. bɪɑnd wʌɾ ivən jə kən noʊ. tʃuz jəɹ mɛn kwɪkli. naʊ ɡoʊ. æsk mi noʊ mɔɹ. ən ðə laɪt ɹaɪd wɪð ju."

"You will be told what you must know when you reach Alcruna." The Lord Captain Commander suddenly looked more than his age. Absently he plucked at his white tunic, with the golden sunburst of the Children large on the chest. "There are forces at work beyond what you know, Geofram. Beyond what even you can know. Choose your men quickly. Now go. Ask me no more. And the Light ride with you."

naʊ bɔɹnhəl stʃɹeɪɾənd ɪn ɪz sæɾəl, wɝkɪŋ ə nɑɾ aʊɾ ə hɪz bæk. aɪm ɡɛɾɪŋ oʊld, hi θɔt. ə deɪ ən ə naɪɾ ɪn ðə sæɾəl, wɪð tu pɔzəz tə wɔɾɝ ðə hɔɹsəz, ən i fɛlt ɛvɹi ɡɹeɪ hɛɹ ɑn ɪz hɛd. hi wəd nɑɾ ivən əv noʊɾəst ə fju jɪɹz əɡoʊ. ət list aɪ hæv nɑt kɪld ɛni ɪnəsəns. hi kəd bi əz hɑɹɾ ɑn dɑɹkfɹɛnz əz ɛni mæn swɔɹn tə ðə laɪt - dɑɹkfɹɛnz mʌs bi dɪstʃɹɔɪd bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ pʊl ðə hoʊl wɝld ʌndɝ ðə ʃædoʊ - bʌɾ i wɑntəd tə bi ʃʊɹ ðeɪ wɝ dɑɹkfɹɛnz fɝst. ɪt hæd bɪn dɪfəkəlt əvɔɪɾɪŋ tæɹɑbənɝ aɪz wɪð soʊ mɛni mɛn, ivən ɪn ðə bækaʊntʃɹi, bʌɾ i hæd mænədʒd ɪt. noʊ tʌŋz hæd niɾəd tə bi saɪlənst.

Now Bornhald straightened in his saddle, working a knot out of his back. I am getting old, he thought. A day and a night in the saddle, with two pauses to water the horses, and he felt every gray hair on his head. He would not even have noticed a few years ago. At least I have not killed any innocents. He could be as hard on Darkfriends as any man sworn to the Light - Darkfriends must be destroyed before they pulled the whole world under the Shadow - but he wanted to be sure they were Darkfriends first. It had been difficult avoiding Taraboner eyes with so many men, even in the backcountry, but he had managed it. No tongues had needed to be silenced.

ðə skaʊts i hæd sɛn aʊt keɪm ɹaɪɾɪŋ bæk, ən bɪhaɪn əm keɪm mɔɹ mɛn ɪn waɪt kloʊks, səm kæɹiɪŋ tɔɹtʃɪz tə ɹuən ðə naɪt vɪʒən ʌv ɛvɹiwʌn ət ðə hɛɾ ə ðə kɑləm. wɪð ə mʌɾɝd kɝs, bɔɹnhəld ɔɹɾɝd ə hɔlt waɪl i stʌɾid ðoʊz u keɪm tə mit hɪm.

The scouts he had sent out came riding back, and behind them came more men in white cloaks, some carrying torches to ruin the night vision of everyone at the head of the column. With a muttered curse, Bornhald ordered a halt while he studied those who came to meet him.

ðɛɹ kloʊks bɔɹ ðə seɪm ɡoʊldən sʌnbɝst ɑn ðə bɹɛst əz hɪz, ðə seɪm əz ɛvɹi tʃaɪld ə ðə laɪt, ən ðɛɹ liɾɝ ivən hæd ɡoʊldən nɑts ə ɹæŋk bɪloʊ ɪɾ ɪkwɪvələn tə bɔɹnhəlz. bʌt bɪhaɪn ðɛɹ sʌnbɝsts wɝ ɹɛd ʃɛpɝdz kɹʊks. kwɛstʃənɝz. wɪð hɑɾ aɪɝnz ən pɪntʃɝz ən dʒɹɪpɪŋ wɔɾɝ ðə kwɛstʃənɝz pʊl kənfɛʃən ən ɹɪpɛntəns fɹəm dɑɹkfɹɛnz, bʌt ðəɹ wɝ ðoʊz u sɛd ðeɪ dɪsaɪɾɪd ɡɪl bɪfɔɹ ɛvɝ ðeɪ bɪɡæn. dʒɛəfɹæm bɔɹnhəld wɑz wʌn u sɛɾ ɪt.

Their cloaks bore the same golden sunburst on the breast as his, the same as every Child of the Light, and their leader even had golden knots of rank below it equivalent to Bornhald's. But behind their sunbursts were red shepherd's crooks. Questioners. With hot irons and pinchers and dripping water the Questioners pulled confession and repentance from Darkfriends, but there were those who said they decided guilt before ever they began. Geofram Bornhald was one who said it.

aɪ hæv bɪn sɛn hɪɹ tə mit kwɛstʃənɝz?

I have been sent here to meet Questioners?

"wi hæv bɪn weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ju, lɔɹd kæptən bɔɹnhəld," ðə liɾɝ sɛɾ ɪn ə hɑɹʃ vɔɪs. hi wɑz ə tɔl, hʊk-noʊz mæn wɪð ðə ɡlim ə sɝɾənti ɪn ɪz aɪz ðəɾ ɛvɹi kwɛstʃənɝ hæd. "ju cʊɾə meɪd bɛɾɝ taɪm. aɪm aɪnɝ sɹən, sɛkən tə dʒeɪitʃɪm kæɹaɪɾɪn, hu kəmænz ðə hæn ə ðə laɪɾ ɪn tæɹɑbən." ðə hæn ə ðə laɪt - ðə hæn ðət dʌɡ aʊt tʃɹuθ, soʊ ðeɪ sɛd. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt laɪk ðə neɪm kwɛstʃənɝz. "ðɛɹ ɪz ə bɹɪdʒ ət ðə vɪlədʒ. hæv jəɹ mɛn muv əkɹɔs. wɪl tɔk ɪn ði ɪn. ɪts sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli kʌmftəɹbəl."

"We have been waiting for you, Lord Captain Bornhald," the leader said in a harsh voice. He was a tall, hook-nosed man with the gleam of certainty in his eyes that every Questioner had. "You could have made better time. I am Einor Saren, second to Jaichim Carridin, who commands the Hand of the Light in Tarabon." The Hand of the Light - the Hand that dug out truth, so they said. They did not like the name Questioners. "There is a bridge at the village. Have your men move across. We will talk in the inn. It is surprisingly comfortable."

"aɪ wɑz toʊl baɪ ðə lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ hɪmsɛlf tə əvɔɪɾ ɔl aɪz."

"I was told by the Lord Captain Commander himself to avoid all eyes."

"ðə vɪlədʒ əz bɪn . . . pæsəfaɪd. naʊ muv jəɹ mɛn. aɪ kəmænd, naʊ. aɪ hæv ɔɹɾɝz wɪð ðə lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝz sil, ɪf jə daʊt."

"The village has been . . . pacified. Now move your men. I command, now. I have orders with the Lord Captain Commander's seal, if you doubt."

bɔɹnhəl səpɹɛs ðə ɡɹaʊl ðət ɹoʊz ɪn ɪz θɹoʊt. pæsəfaɪd. hi wʌndɝɾ ɪf ðə bɑɾiz hæd bɪn paɪld aʊtsaɪd ðə vɪlədʒ, əɹ ɪf ðeɪ hæd bɪn θɹoʊn ɪndə ðə ɹɪvɝ. ɪt wəd bi laɪk ðə kwɛstʃənɝz, koʊld ɪnʌf tə kɪl ən ɪntaɪɝ vɪlədʒ fəɹ sikɹəsi ən stupəɾ ɪnʌf tə θɹoʊ ðə bɑɾiz ɪndə ðə ɹɪvɝ tə floʊt daʊnstʃɹim ən tʃɹʌmpət ðɛɹ did fɹəm ælkɹunə tə tæntʃəkoʊ. "wʌɾ aɪ daʊɾ ɪz waɪ aɪm ɪn tæɹɑbən wɪð tu θaʊzən mɛn, kwɛstʃənɝ."

Bornhald suppressed the growl that rose in his throat. Pacified. He wondered if the bodies had been piled outside the village, or if they had been thrown into the river. It would be like the Questioners, cold enough to kill an entire village for secrecy and stupid enough to throw the bodies into the river to float downstream and trumpet their deed from Alcruna to Tanchico. "What I doubt is why I am in Tarabon with two thousand men, Questioner."

sɹənz feɪs taɪɾənd, bʌɾ ɪz vɔɪs ɹɪmeɪn hɑɹʃ ən dɪmændɪŋ. "ɪɾ ɪz sɪmpəl, lɔɹd kæptən. ðəɹ ɑɹ taʊnz ən vɪlədʒəz əkɹɔs ɑlməθ pleɪn wɪð nʌn ɪn əθɔɹəɾi əbʌv ə meɪɝ əɹ ə taʊn kaʊnsəl. ɪts pæs taɪm ðeɪ wɝ bɹɔt tə ðə laɪt. ðəɹ wɪl bi mɛni dɑɹkfɹɛnz ɪn sətʃ pleɪsəz."

Saren's face tightened, but his voice remained harsh and demanding. "It is simple, Lord Captain. There are towns and villages across Almoth Plain with none in authority above a mayor or a Town Council. It is past time they were brought to the Light. There will be many Darkfriends in such places."

bɔɹnhəlz hɔɹs stæmpt. "ɑɹ jə seɪɪŋ, sɹən, ðəɾ aɪv bɹɔɾ ən ɪntaɪɝ lidʒən əkɹɔs moʊst ə tæɹɑbən ɪn sikɹəsi tə ɹuɾ ə fju dɑɹkfɹɛnz aʊɾ ə səm ɡɹʌbi vɪlədʒəz?"

Bornhald's horse stamped. "Are you saying, Saren, that I've brought an entire legion across most of Tarabon in secrecy to root a few Darkfriends out of some grubby villages?"

"ju ɑɹ hɪɹ tə də əz jə ɑɹ toʊld, bɔɹnhəld. tə də ðə wɝk ə ðə laɪt! əɹ ɑɹ jə slaɪɾɪŋ fɹəm ðə laɪt?" sɹənz smaɪl wɑz ə ɡɹɪmɑs. "ɪf bæɾəl ɪz wʌt jə sik, jə meɪ hæv jəɹ tʃæns. ðə stʃɹeɪnʒɝz əv ə ɡɹeɪt fɔɹs ɑn toʊmən hɛd, mɔɹ ðən tæɹɑbən ən ɑɹæd dumən təɡɛðɝ meɪ bi eɪbəl tə hoʊld, ivən ɪf ðeɪ kən stɑp ðɛɹ oʊn bɪkɝɪŋ lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə wɝk təɡɛðɝ. ɪf ðə stʃɹeɪnʒɝz bɹeɪk θɹu, jəl əv ɔl ðə faɪɾɪŋ jə kən hændəl. ðə tæɹɑbənɝz kleɪm ðə stʃɹeɪnʒɝz ɑɹ mɑnstɝz, kɹitʃɝz ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn. səm seɪ ðeɪv ɛɛs sədaɪ tə faɪt fəɹ ðɛm. ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹ dɑɹkfɹɛnz, ðiz stʃɹeɪnʒɝz, ðəl əv tə bi dɛlt wɪð, tu. ɪn ðɛɹ tɝn."

"You are here to do as you are told, Bornhald. To do the work of the Light! Or are you sliding from the Light?" Saren's smile was a grimace. "If battle is what you seek, you may have your chance. The strangers have a great force on Toman Head, more than Tarabon and Arad Doman together may be able to hold, even if they can stop their own bickering long enough to work together. If the strangers break through, you will have all the fighting you can handle. The Taraboners claim the strangers are monsters, creatures of the Dark One. Some say they have Aes Sedai to fight for them. If they are Darkfriends, these strangers, they will have to be dealt with, too. In their turn."

fəɹ ə moʊmənt, bɔɹnhəl stɑp bɹiðɪŋ. "ðɛn ðə ɹumɝz ɑɹ tʃɹu. ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz ɑɹmiz əv ɹɪtɝnd."

For a moment, Bornhald stopped breathing. "Then the rumors are true. Artur Hawkwing's armies have returned."

"stʃɹeɪnʒɝz," sɹən sɛd flætli. hi saʊndəɾ əz ɪf i ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪd hævɪŋ mɛnʃən ðɛm. "stʃɹeɪnʒɝz, ən pɹɑbli dɑɹkfɹɛnz, fɹəm wɛɹɛvɝ ðeɪ keɪm. ðəɾ ɪz ɔl wi noʊ, ən ɔl jə nid tə noʊ. ðeɪ də nɑt kənsɝn jə naʊ. wəɹ weɪstɪŋ taɪm. muv jəɹ mɛn əkɹɔs ðə ɹɪvɝ, bɔɹnhəld. əl ɡɪv jə jəɹ ɔɹɾɝz ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ." hi wɝld ɪz hɔɹs ən ɡæləp bæk ðə weɪ hi hæd kʌm, hɪz tɔɹtʃbɛɹɝz ɹaɪɾɪŋ əɾ ɪz hilz.

"Strangers," Saren said flatly. He sounded as if he regretted having mentioned them. "Strangers, and probably Darkfriends, from wherever they came. That is all we know, and all you need to know. They do not concern you now. We are wasting time. Move your men across the river, Bornhald. I will give you your orders in the village." He whirled his horse and galloped back the way he had come, his torchbearers riding at his heels.

bɔɹnhəl kloʊzd ɪz aɪz tə heɪsən ðə ɹɪtɝn ə hɪz naɪt saɪt. wəɹ biɪŋ juz laɪk stoʊnz ɑn ə bɔɹd. "baɪɑɝ!" hi oʊpən ɪz aɪz əz ɪz sɛkən əpɪɹɾ əɾ ɪz saɪd, stɪfənɪŋ ɪn ɪz sæɾəl bɪfɔɹ ðə lɔɹd kæptən. ðə ɡɔnt-feɪs mæn hæɾ ɔlmoʊs ðə kwɛstʃənɝz laɪɾ ɪn ɪz aɪz, bʌɾ i wɑz ə ɡʊd soʊlʒɝ dɪspaɪt. "ðɛɹ ɪz ə bɹɪdʒ əhɛd. muv ðə lidʒən əkɹɔs ðə ɹɪvɝ ən meɪk kæmp. əl dʒɔɪn jə əz sun əz aɪ kæn."

Bornhald closed his eyes to hasten the return of his night sight. We are being used like stones on a board. "Byar!" He opened his eyes as his second appeared at his side, stiffening in his saddle before the Lord Captain. The gaunt-faced man had almost the Questioner's light in his eyes, but he was a good soldier despite. "There is a bridge ahead. Move the legion across the river and make camp. I will join you as soon as I can."

hi ɡæðɝɾ ɪz ɹeɪnz ən ɹoʊɾ ɪn ðə dɝɛkʃən ðə kwɛstʃənɝ hæd teɪkən. stoʊnz ɑn ə bɔɹd. bʌɾ u ɪz muvɪŋ ʌs? ən waɪ?

He gathered his reins and rode in the direction the Questioner had taken. Stones on a board. But who is moving us? And why?

æftɝnun ʃædoʊz ɡeɪv weɪ tə ivnɪŋ əz liɑnʒɹɪn meɪɾ əɹ weɪ θɹu ðə wɪmənz əpɑɹtməns. bɪɑn ði æɹoʊslɪts, dɑɹknəs ɡɹu ən pɹɛst ɑn ðə laɪt fɹəm ðə læmps ɪn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ. twaɪlaɪt wɑz ə tʃɹʌbəl taɪm fəɹ liɑnʒɹɪn ə leɪt, ðəɾ ən dɔn. ət dɔn ðə deɪ wɑz bɔɹn, dʒʌst əz twaɪlaɪt ɡeɪv bɝθ tə naɪt, bʌɾ ət dɔn, naɪt daɪd, ən ət twaɪlaɪt, deɪ. ðə dɑɹk wʌnz paʊɝ wɑz ɹuɾəd ɪn dɛθ; hi ɡeɪn paʊɝ fɹəm dɛθ, ən ət ðoʊz taɪmz ʃi θɔt ʃi kəd fil ɪz paʊɝ stɝɪŋ. sʌmθɪŋ stɝɾ ɪn ðə hæf dɑɹk, ət list. sʌmθɪŋ ʃi ɔlmoʊs θɔt ʃi kəd kætʃ ɪf ʃi tɝn kwɪkli ɪnʌf, sʌmθɪŋ ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ʃi kəd si ɪf ʃi lʊk hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf.

Afternoon shadows gave way to evening as Liandrin made her way through the women's apartments. Beyond the arrowslits, darkness grew and pressed on the light from the lamps in the corridor. Twilight was a troubled time for Liandrin of late, that and dawn. At dawn the day was born, just as twilight gave birth to night, but at dawn, night died, and at twilight, day. The Dark One's power was rooted in death; he gained power from death, and at those times she thought she could feel his power stirring. Something stirred in the half dark, at least. Something she almost thought she could catch if she turned quickly enough, something she was sure she could see if she looked hard enough.

sɝvɪŋ wɪmən ɪn blæk-ænd-ɡoʊl kɝtsiɾ əz ʃi pæst, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt ɹɪspɑnd. ʃi kɛpt əɹ aɪz fɪkst stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛd, ən dɪd nɑt si ðɛm.

Serving women in black-and-gold curtsied as she passed, but she did not respond. She kept her eyes fixed straight ahead, and did not see them.

ət ðə dɔɹ ʃi sɔt, ʃi pɔz fəɹ ə kwɪk ɡlæns ʌp ən daʊn ðə hɔl. ði oʊnli wɪmən ɪn saɪt wɝ sɝvəns; ðəɹ wɝ noʊ mɛn, ʌv kɔɹs. ʃi pʊʃt oʊpən ðə dɔɹ ən wɛn ɪn wɪθaʊt nɑkɪŋ.

At the door she sought, she paused for a quick glance up and down the hall. The only women in sight were servants; there were no men, of course. She pushed open the door and went in without knocking.

ði aʊɾɝ ɹum ə ðə leɪɾi əmælisəz tʃeɪmbɝz wɑz bɹaɪtli lɪt, ən ə bleɪzɪŋ faɪɝ ɑn ðə hɑɹθ hɛl bæk ðə tʃɪl ə ðə ʃaɪnɝən naɪt. əmælisə ən əɹ leɪɾiz sæɾ əbaʊt ðə ɹum, ɪn tʃɛɹz ən ɑn ðə leɪɝd kɑɹpəts, lɪsnɪŋ waɪl wʌn ə ðɛɹ nʌmbɝ, stændɪŋ, ɹɛɾ əlaʊd tə ðɛm. ɪt wɑz ðə dæns ə ðə hɔk ən ðə hʌmɪŋbɝd, baɪ teɪvən ɛɝwɪn, wɪtʃ pɝpɔɹɾɪd tə sɛt fɔɹθ ðə pɹɑpɝ kʌndəkt ə mɛn təwɔɹd wɪmən ən wɪmən təwɔɹd mɛn. liɑnʒɹɪnz maʊθ taɪɾənd; ʃi sɝɾənli hæd nɑt ɹɛɾ ɪt, bʌt ʃi hæd hɝɾ əz mʌtʃ əz ʃi niɾəd əbaʊɾ ɪt. əmælisə ən əɹ leɪɾiz ɡɹiɾəd itʃ pɹənaʊnsmənt wɪð ɡeɪlz ə læftɝ, fɔlɪŋ əɡɛnst itʃ ʌðɝ ən dʒɹʌmɪŋ ðɛɹ hilz ɑn ðə kɑɹpəts laɪk ɡɝlz.

The outer room of the Lady Amalisa's chambers was brightly lit, and a blazing fire on the hearth held back the chill of the Shienaran night. Amalisa and her ladies sat about the room, in chairs and on the layered carpets, listening while one of their number, standing, read aloud to them. It was The Dance of the Hawk and the Hummingbird, by Teven Aerwin, which purported to set forth the proper conduct of men toward women and women toward men. Liandrin's mouth tightened; she certainly had not read it, but she had heard as much as she needed about it. Amalisa and her ladies greeted each pronouncement with gales of laughter, falling against each other and drumming their heels on the carpets like girls.

ðə ɹiɾɝ wɑz ðə fɝs tə bɪkʌm əwɛɹ ə liɑnʒɹɪnz pɹɛzəns. ʃi kʌɾ ɔf wɪð ə sɝpɹaɪzd waɪɾənɪŋ ə hɝ aɪz. ði ʌðɝz tɝn tə si wʌt ʃi wɑz stɛɹɪŋ æt, ən saɪləns ɹipleɪs læftɝ. ɔl bʌɾ əmælisə skɹæmbəl tə ðɛɹ fit, heɪstəli smuðɪŋ hɛɹ ən skɝts.

The reader was the first to become aware of Liandrin's presence. She cut off with a surprised widening of her eyes. The others turned to see what she was staring at, and silence replaced laughter. All but Amalisa scrambled to their feet, hastily smoothing hair and skirts.

ðə leɪɾi əmælisə ɹoʊz ɡɹeɪsfəli, wɪð ə smaɪl. "ju ɑnɝ əs wɪð jəɹ pɹɛzəns, liɑnʒɹɪn. ðɪs ɪz ə moʊs plɛzən sɝpɹaɪz. aɪ dɪd nɑɾ ɪkspɛk jə əntɪl təmɑɹoʊ. aɪ θɔt jə wəd wɑnə ɹɛst æftɝ jəɹ lɔŋ dʒaʊɹ - "

The Lady Amalisa rose gracefully, with a smile. "You honor us with your presence, Liandrin. This is a most pleasant surprise. I did not expect you until tomorrow. I thought you would want to rest after your long jour - "

liɑnʒɹɪn kʌɾ əɹ ɔf ʃɑɹpli, ədʒɹɛsɪŋ ði ɛɹ. "aɪ wɪl spik tə ðə leɪɾi əmælisə əloʊn. ɔl ə jəl liv. naʊ."

Liandrin cut her off sharply, addressing the air. "I will speak to the Lady Amalisa alone. All of you will leave. Now."

ðəɹ wɑz ə moʊmən ə ʃɑk saɪləns, ðən ði ʌðɝ wɪmən meɪd ðɛɹ ɡʊdbaɪz tə əmælisə. wʌn baɪ wʌn ðeɪ kɝtsid tə liɑnʒɹɪn, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑɾ æknɑlɪdʒ ðɛm. ʃi kəntɪnjud tə stɛɹ stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛɾ ət nʌθɪŋ, bʌt ʃi sɔ ðɛm, ən hɝd. ɑnɹəfɪks ɔfɝd wɪð bɹɛθi əniz ət ði ɛɛs sədaɪz mud. aɪz fɔlɪŋ wən ʃi ɪɡnɔɹd ðɛm. ðeɪ skwiz pæst əɹ tə ðə dɔɹ, pɹɛsɪŋ bæk ɔkwɝdli soʊ ðɛɹ skɝts dɪd nɑt dɪstɝb hɝz.

There was a moment of shocked silence, then the other women made their goodbyes to Amalisa. One by one they curtsied to Liandrin, but she did not acknowledge them. She continued to stare straight ahead at nothing, but she saw them, and heard. Honorifics offered with breathy unease at the Aes Sedai's mood. Eyes falling when she ignored them. They squeezed past her to the door, pressing back awkwardly so their skirts did not disturb hers.

əz ðə dɔɹ kloʊz bɪhaɪn ðə læst ə ðɛm, əmælisə sɛd, "liɑnʒɹɪn, aɪ də nɑɾ ʌndɝst - "

As the door closed behind the last of them, Amalisa said, "Liandrin, I do not underst - "

"du jə wɔk ɪn ðə laɪt, maɪ dɔɾɝ?" ðəɹ wəd bi nʌn ə ðət fulɪʃnəs ə kɔlɪŋ əɹ sɪstɝ hɪɹ. ði ʌðɝ wʊmən wɑz oʊldɝ baɪ səm jɪɹz, bʌt ði eɪntʃən fɔɹmz wəd bi əbzɝvd. haʊɛvɝ lɔŋ ðeɪ hæd bɪn fɝɡɑɾən, ɪt wɑz taɪm ðeɪ wɝ ɹɪmɛmbɝd.

"Do you walk in the Light, my daughter?" There would be none of that foolishness of calling her sister here. The other woman was older by some years, but the ancient forms would be observed. However long they had been forgotten, it was time they were remembered.

əz sun əz ðə kwɛstʃən wɑz aʊɾ ə hɝ maʊθ, ðoʊ, liɑnʒɹɪn ɹilaɪzd ʃi hæd meɪɾ ə mɪsteɪk. ɪt wɑz ə kwɛstʃən ɡɛɹəntid tə kɑz daʊɾ ən æŋzaɪəɾi, kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌɾ əmælisəz bæk stɪfənd, ən əɹ feɪs hɑɹɾənd.

As soon as the question was out of her mouth, though, Liandrin realized she had made a mistake. It was a question guaranteed to cause doubt and anxiety, coming from an Aes Sedai, but Amalisa's back stiffened, and her face hardened.

"ðæɾ ɪz ən ɪnsəlt, liɑnʒɹɪn sədaɪ. aɪm ʃaɪnɝən, ʌv ə noʊbəl haʊs ən ðə blʌɾ ə soʊlʒɝz. maɪ laɪn əz fɔt ðə ʃædoʊ sɪns bɪfɔɹ ðəɹ wɑz ə ʃaɪnɝ, θɹi θaʊzən jɪɹz wɪθaʊt feɪl əɹ ə deɪz wiknəs."

"That is an insult, Liandrin Sedai. I am Shienaran, of a noble House and the blood of soldiers. My line has fought the Shadow since before there was a Shienar, three thousand years without fail or a day's weakness."

liɑnʒɹɪn ʃɪftəɾ əɹ pɔɪn ʌv ətæk, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt ɹitʃɹit. stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə ɹum, ʃi tʊk ðə lɛðɝ-baʊn kɑpi ʌv ðə dæns ə ðə hɔk ən ðə hʌmɪŋbɝd fɹəm ðə mæntəlpis ən hɛftəɾ ɪt wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪt. "ɪn ʃaɪnɝ əbʌv ʌðɝ lænz, maɪ dɔɾɝ, ðə laɪt mʌs bi pɹɛʃəs, ən ðə ʃædoʊ fɪɹd." kæʒəwəli ʃi θɹu ðə bʊk ɪndə ðə faɪɝ. fleɪmz lɛpt əz ɪf ɪt wɝ ə lɔɡ ʌv fætwʊd, θʌndɝɪŋ əz ðeɪ lɪkt ʌp ðə tʃɪmni. ɪn ðə seɪm ɪnstən ɛvɹi læmp ɪn ðə ɹum flɛɹd, hɪsɪŋ, soʊ fɪɹsli dɪd ðeɪ bɝn, flʌɾɪŋ ðə tʃeɪmbɝ wɪð laɪt. "hɪɹ əbʌv ɔl. hɪɹ, soʊ kloʊs tə ðə kɝs blaɪt, wɛɹ kɝʌpʃən weɪts. hɪɹ, ivən wʌn u θɪŋks i wɔks ɪn ðə laɪt meɪ stɪl bi kɝʌptɪd baɪ ðə ʃædoʊ."

Liandrin shifted her point of attack, but she did not retreat. Striding across the room, she took the leather-bound copy of The Dance of the Hawk and the Hummingbird from the mantelpiece and hefted it without looking at it. "In Shienar above other lands, my daughter, the Light must be precious, and the Shadow feared." Casually she threw the book into the fire. Flames leaped as if it were a log of fatwood, thundering as they licked up the chimney. In the same instant every lamp in the room flared, hissing, so fiercely did they burn, flooding the chamber with light. "Here above all. Here, so close to the cursed Blight, where corruption waits. Here, even one who thinks he walks in the Light may still be corrupted by the Shadow."

bidz ə swɛt ɡlɪsən ɑn əmælisəz fɔɹhɛd. ðə hænd ʃi hæd ɹeɪzd ɪn pɹoʊɾɛst fəɹ əɹ bʊk fɛl sloʊli tə hɝ saɪd. hɝ fitʃɝz stɪl hɛl fɝm, bʌt liɑnʒɹɪn sɔ hɝ swɑloʊ, ən əɹ fit ʃɪft. "aɪ də nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd, liɑnʒɹɪn sədaɪ. ɪz ɪt ðə bʊk? ɪts oʊnli fulɪʃnəs."

Beads of sweat glistened on Amalisa's forehead. The hand she had raised in protest for her book fell slowly to her side. Her features still held firm, but Liandrin saw her swallow, and her feet shift. "I do not understand, Liandrin Sedai. Is it the book? It is only foolishness."

ðəɹ wɑz ə feɪn kweɪvɝ ɪn əɹ vɔɪs. ɡʊd. ɡlæs læmp mæntəlz kɹækt əz ðə fleɪmz lɛp haɪɝ ən hɑɾɝ, laɪɾɪŋ ðə ɹum əz bɹaɪɾ əz ənʃɛltɝd nun. əmælisə stʊɾ əz stɪf əz ə poʊst, hɝ feɪs taɪɾ əz ʃi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə skwɪnt.

There was a faint quaver in her voice. Good. Glass lamp mantles cracked as the flames leaped higher and hotter, lighting the room as bright as unsheltered noon. Amalisa stood as stiff as a post, her face tight as she tried not to squint.

"ɪɾ ɪz jə hu ɑɹ fulɪʃ, maɪ dɔɾɝ. aɪ kɛɹ nʌθɪŋ fəɹ bʊks. hɪɹ, mɛn ɛntɝ ðə blaɪt, ən wɔk ɪn ɪts teɪnt. ɪn ðə vɛɹi ʃædoʊ. waɪ wʌndɝ jə ðət ðət teɪn meɪ sip ɪndə ðɛm? wɛðɝ əɹ nɑɾ əɡɛns ðɛɹ wɪl, stɪl ɪt meɪ sip. waɪ θɪŋk jə ði æmɪɝlɪn sit hɝsɛlf əz kʌm?"

"It is you who are foolish, my daughter. I care nothing for books. Here, men enter the Blight, and walk in its taint. In the very Shadow. Why wonder you that that taint may seep into them? Whether or not against their will, still it may seep. Why think you the Amyrlin Seat herself has come?"

"noʊ." ɪt wɑz ə ɡæsp.

"No." It was a gasp.

"ʌv ðə ɹɛɾ æm aɪ, maɪ dɔɾɝ," liɑnʒɹɪn sɛd ɹɪlɛnləsli. "aɪ hʌn ɔl mɛn kɝʌptɪd."

"Of the Red am I, my daughter," Liandrin said relentlessly. "I hunt all men corrupted."

"aɪ doʊn ʌndɝstænd."

"I don't understand."

"nɑɾ oʊnli ðoʊz faʊl wʌnz u tʃɹaɪ ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ɔl mɛn kɝʌptɪd. haɪ ən loʊ də aɪ hʌnt."

"Not only those foul ones who try the One Power. All men corrupted. High and low do I hunt."

"aɪ doʊnt. . . ." əmælisə lɪkt əɹ lɪps ənstɛɾəli ən meɪɾ ə vɪzəbəl ɛfɝt tə ɡæðɝ hɝsɛlf. "aɪ də nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd, liɑnʒɹɪn sədaɪ. pliz. . . ."

"I don't. . . ." Amalisa licked her lips unsteadily and made a visible effort to gather herself. "I do not understand, Liandrin Sedai. Please. . . ."

"haɪ ivən bɪfɔɹ loʊ."

"High even before low."

"noʊ!" əz ɪf səm ɪnvɪzəbəl səpɔɹt hæd vænɪʃt, əmælisə fɛl tə hɝ niz, ən əɹ hɛd dʒɹɑpt. "pliz, liɑnʒɹɪn sədaɪ, seɪ jə də nɑt min eɪɡəlmɝ. ɪt kænɑt bi hɪm."

"No!" As if some invisible support had vanished, Amalisa fell to her knees, and her head dropped. "Please, Liandrin Sedai, say you do not mean Agelmar. It cannot be him."

ɪn ðət moʊmən ə daʊɾ ən kənfjuʒən, liɑnʒɹɪn stʃɹʌk. ʃi dɪd nɑt muv, bʌt læʃt aʊt wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ. əmælisə ɡæspt ən ɡeɪv ə dʒɝk, əz ɪf ʃi hæd bɪn pɹɪkt wɪð ə niɾəl, ən liɑnʒɹɪnz pɛtʃələn maʊθ pɝkt ɪn ə smaɪl.

In that moment of doubt and confusion, Liandrin struck. She did not move, but lashed out with the One Power. Amalisa gasped and gave a jerk, as if she had been pricked with a needle, and Liandrin's petulant mouth perked in a smile.

ðɪs wɑz əɹ oʊn spɛʃəl tʃɹɪk fɹəm tʃaɪldhʊd, ðə fɝs lɝn ə hɝ əbɪləɾiz. ɪt hæd bɪn fɔɹbɪɾən tə hɝ əz sun əz ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz dɪskʌvɝɾ ɪt, bʌt tə liɑnʒɹɪn ðəɾ oʊnli mɛnt wʌn mɔɹ θɪŋ ʃi niɾəd tə kənsil fɹəm ðoʊz u wɝ dʒɛləs ə hɝ.

This was her own special trick from childhood, the first learned of her abilities. It had been forbidden to her as soon as the Mistress of Novices discovered it, but to Liandrin that only meant one more thing she needed to conceal from those who were jealous of her.

ʃi stʃɹoʊd fɔɹwɝɾ ən pʊld əmælisəz tʃɪn ʌp. ðə mɛɾəl ðət hæd stɪfən əɹ wɑz stɪl ðɛɹ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz bæzɝ mɛɾəl naʊ, mæliəbəl tə ðə ɹaɪt pɹɛʃɝz. tɪɹz tʃɹɪkəl fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝz ʌv əmælisəz aɪz, ɡlɪsnɪŋ ɑn əɹ tʃiks. liɑnʒɹɪn lɛt ðə faɪɝz daɪ bæk tə nɔɹməl; ðəɹ wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɛni nid fəɹ sʌtʃ. ʃi sɔfən əɹ wɝdz, bʌɾ əɹ vɔɪs wɑz əz ənjildɪŋ əz stil.

She strode forward and pulled Amalisa's chin up. The metal that had stiffened her was still there, but it was baser metal now, malleable to the right pressures. Tears trickled from the corners of Amalisa's eyes, glistening on her cheeks. Liandrin let the fires die back to normal; there was no longer any need for such. She softened her words, but her voice was as unyielding as steel.

"dɔɾɝ, noʊ wʌn wɑns tə si jə ən eɪɡəlmɝ θɹoʊn tə ðə pipəl əz dɑɹkfɹɛnz. əl hɛlp ju, bʌt jə mʌs hɛlp."

"Daughter, no one wants to see you and Agelmar thrown to the people as Darkfriends. I will help you, but you must help."

"eɪtʃ-hɛlp ju?" əmælisə pʊɾ əɹ hænz tə hɝ tɛmpəlz; ʃi lʊkt kənfjuzd. "pliz, liɑnʒɹɪn sədaɪ, aɪ doʊnt . . . ʌndɝstænd. ɪts ɔl soʊ. . . . ɪts ɔl. . . ."

"H-help you?" Amalisa put her hands to her temples; she looked confused. "Please, Liandrin Sedai, I don't . . . understand. It is all so. . . . It's all. . . ."

ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə pɝfəkt əbɪləɾi; liɑnʒɹɪn kəd nɑt fɔɹs ɛniwʌn tə də wʌt ʃi wɑntəd - ðoʊ ʃi hæd tʃɹaɪd; oʊ, haʊ ʃi hæd tʃɹaɪd. bʌt ʃi kəɾ oʊpən əm waɪd tə hɝ ɑɹɡjəməns, meɪk əm wɑnə bɪliv hɝ, wɑn mɔɹ ðən ɛniθɪŋ tə bi kənvɪnst ə hɝ ɹaɪtnəs.

It was not a perfect ability; Liandrin could not force anyone to do what she wanted - though she had tried; oh, how she had tried. But she could open them wide to her arguments, make them want to believe her, want more than anything to be convinced of her rightness.

"oʊbeɪ, dɔɾɝ. oʊbeɪ, ən ænsɝ maɪ kwɛstʃənz tʃɹuθfəli, ən aɪ pɹɑməs ðət noʊ wʌn wɪl spik ə jə ən eɪɡəlmɝ əz dɑɹkfɹɛnz. jəl nɑt bi dʒɹæɡd neɪkəd θɹu ðə stʃɹits, tə bi flɑɡd fɹəm ðə sɪɾi ɪf ðə pipəl də nɑt tɛɹ jə tə pisəz fɝst. əl nɑt lɛt ðɪs hæpən. jə ʌndɝstænd?"

"Obey, daughter. Obey, and answer my questions truthfully, and I promise that no one will speak of you and Agelmar as Darkfriends. You will not be dragged naked through the streets, to be flogged from the city if the people do not tear you to pieces first. I will not let this happen. You understand?"

"jɛs, liɑnʒɹɪn sədaɪ, jɛs. əl də əz jə seɪ ən ænsɝ jə tʃɹuli."

"Yes, Liandrin Sedai, yes. I will do as you say and answer you truly."

liɑnʒɹɪn stʃɹeɪɾənd, lʊkɪŋ daʊn ət ði ʌðɝ wʊmən. ðə leɪɾi əmælisə steɪɾ əz ʃi wɑz, nilɪŋ, hɝ feɪs əz oʊpən əz ə tʃaɪlz, ə tʃaɪld weɪɾɪŋ tə bi kʌmfɝɾɪd ən hɛlp baɪ sʌmwʌn waɪzɝ ən stʃɹɔŋɝ. ðəɹ wɑz ə ɹaɪtnəs əbaʊɾ ɪt tə liɑnʒɹɪn. ʃi hæd nɛvɝ ʌndɝstʊd waɪ ə sɪmpəl baʊ əɹ kɝtsi wɑz səfɪʃən fəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ wən mɛn ən wɪmən nɛl tə kɪŋz ən kwinz. wʌt kwin əz wɪðɪn əɹ maɪ paʊɝ? hɝ maʊθ twɪstəɾ æŋɡɹəli, ən əmælisə ʃɪvɝd.

Liandrin straightened, looking down at the other woman. The Lady Amalisa stayed as she was, kneeling, her face as open as a child's, a child waiting to be comforted and helped by someone wiser and stronger. There was a rightness about it to Liandrin. She had never understood why a simple bow or curtsy was sufficient for Aes Sedai when men and women knelt to kings and queens. What queen has within her my power? Her mouth twisted angrily, and Amalisa shivered.

"bi izi ɪn jɝsɛlf, maɪ dɔɾɝ. aɪ hæv kʌm tə hɛlp ju, nɑt tə pʌnɪʃ. oʊnli ðoʊz u dɪzɝv ɪɾəl bi pʌnɪʃt. tʃɹuθ oʊnli, spik tə mi."

"Be easy in yourself, my daughter. I have come to help you, not to punish. Only those who deserve it will be punished. Truth only, speak to me."

"aɪ wɪl, liɑnʒɹɪn sədaɪ. aɪ wɪl, aɪ swɛɹ ɪt baɪ maɪ haʊs ən ɑnɝ."

"I will, Liandrin Sedai. I will, I swear it by my House and honor."

"mɔɪɹeɪn keɪm tə fæl dæɹə wɪð ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd."

"Moiraine came to Fal Dara with a Darkfriend."

əmælisə wɑz tu fɹaɪɾənd tə ʃoʊ sɝpɹaɪz. "oʊ, noʊ, liɑnʒɹɪn sədaɪ. noʊ. ðət mæn keɪm leɪɾɝ. hiz ɪn ðə dʌnʒənz naʊ."

Amalisa was too frightened to show surprise. "Oh, no, Liandrin Sedai. No. That man came later. He is in the dungeons now."

"leɪɾɝ, jə seɪ. bʌɾ ɪts tʃɹu ðət ʃi spiks ɔfən wɪð hɪm? ʃiz ɔfən ɪn kʌmpəni wɪð ðɪs dɑɹkfɹɛnd? əloʊn?"

"Later, you say. But it is true that she speaks often with him? She is often in company with this Darkfriend? Alone?"

"ɛs-səmtaɪmz, liɑnʒɹɪn sədaɪ. oʊnli səmtaɪmz. ʃi wɪʃɪz tə faɪn aʊt waɪ hi keɪm hɪɹ. mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ ɪz - " liɑnʒɹɪn hɛld ʌp əɹ hænd ʃɑɹpli, ən əmælisə swɑloʊd wʌtɛvɝ ɛls ʃi hæd bɪn ɡoʊɪŋ tə seɪ.

"S-sometimes, Liandrin Sedai. Only sometimes. She wishes to find out why he came here. Moiraine Sedai is - " Liandrin held up her hand sharply, and Amalisa swallowed whatever else she had been going to say.

"baɪ θɹi jʌŋ mɛn mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz əkʌmpənid. ðɪs aɪ noʊ. wɛɹ ɑɹ ðeɪ? aɪ hæv bɪn tə ðɛɹ ɹumz, ən ðeɪ ɑɹ nɑt tə bi faʊnd."

"By three young men Moiraine was accompanied. This I know. Where are they? I have been to their rooms, and they are not to be found."

"aɪ - aɪ də nɑt noʊ, liɑnʒɹɪn sədaɪ. ðeɪ sim naɪs bɔɪz. ʃʊɹli jə doʊn θɪŋk ðeɪ ɑɹ dɑɹkfɹɛnz."

"I - I do not know, Liandrin Sedai. They seem nice boys. Surely you don't think they are Darkfriends."

"nɑt dɑɹkfɹɛnz, noʊ. wɝs. baɪ fɑɹ mɔɹ deɪnʒɝəs ðən dɑɹkfɹɛnz, maɪ dɔɾɝ. ði ɪntaɪɝ wɝld ɪz ɪn deɪnʒɝ fɹəm ðɛm. ðeɪ mʌs bi faʊnd. jəl kəmæn jəɹ sɝvəns tə sɝtʃ ðə kip, ən jəɹ leɪɾiz, ən jɝsɛlf. ɛvɹi kɹæk ən kɹæni. tə ðɪs, jəl si pɝsənəli. pɝsənəli! ən tə noʊ wʌn wɪl jə spik ʌv ɪt, seɪv ðoʊz aɪ neɪm. nʌn ɛls meɪ noʊ. nʌn. fɹəm fæl dæɹə ɪn sikɹəsi ðiz jʌŋ mɛn mʌs bi ɹimuvd, ən tə tɑɹ vəlɑn teɪkən. ɪn ʌɾɝ sikɹəsi."

"Not Darkfriends, no. Worse. By far more dangerous than Darkfriends, my daughter. The entire world is in danger from them. They must be found. You will command your servants to search the keep, and your ladies, and yourself. Every crack and cranny. To this, you will see personally. Personally! And to no one will you speak of it, save those I name. None else may know. None. From Fal Dara in secrecy these young men must be removed, and to Tar Valon taken. In utter secrecy."

"æz jə kəmænd, liɑnʒɹɪn sədaɪ. bʌɾ aɪ də nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ðə nid fəɹ sikɹəsi. noʊ wʌn hɪɹ wɪl hɪndɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ."

"As you command, Liandrin Sedai. But I do not understand the need for secrecy. No one here will hinder Aes Sedai."

"ʌv ðə blæk ədʒɑ juv hɝd?"

"Of the Black Ajah you have heard?"

əmælisəz aɪz bʌlʒd, ən ʃi lin bæk əweɪ fɹəm liɑnʒɹɪn, ɹeɪzɪŋ əɹ hænz əz ðoʊ tə ʃil hɝsɛlf fɹəm ə bloʊ. "ə vi-vaɪl ɹumɝ, liɑnʒɹɪn sədaɪ. vi-vaɪl. ðəɹ ɑɹ ɛn-noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ hu ɛs-sɝv ðə dɑɹk wʌn. aɪ də nɑt bɪliv ɪt. jə mʌs bɪliv mi! ʌndɝ ðə laɪt, aɪ ɛs-swɛɹ aɪ də nɑt bɪliv ɪt. baɪ maɪ ɑnɝ ən maɪ haʊs, aɪ swɛɹ. . . ."

Amalisa's eyes bulged, and she leaned back away from Liandrin, raising her hands as though to shield herself from a blow. "A v-vile rumor, Liandrin Sedai. V-vile. There are n-no Aes Sedai who s-serve the Dark One. I do not believe it. You must believe me! Under the Light, I s-swear I do not believe it. By my honor and my House, I swear. . . ."

kuli liɑnʒɹɪn lɛɾ əɹ ɡoʊ ɑn, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə læst ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ stʃɹɛŋkθ litʃ aʊɾ ə ði ʌðɝ wʊmən wɪð əɹ oʊn saɪləns. ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd bɪn noʊn tə bɪkʌm æŋɡɹi, vɛɹi æŋɡɹi, wɪð ðoʊz u ivən mɛnʃən ðə blæk ədʒɑ mʌtʃ lɛs ðoʊz u sɛd ðeɪ bɪlivd ɪn ɪts hɪɾən ɛɡzɪstəns. æftɝ ðɪs, wɪð əɹ wɪl ɔlɹɛɾi wikən baɪ ðət lɪɾəl tʃaɪldhʊd tʃɹɪk, əmælisə wəd bi əz kleɪ ɪn əɹ hænz. æftɝ wʌn mɔɹ bloʊ.

Coolly Liandrin let her go on, watching the last remaining strength leach out of the other woman with her own silence. Aes Sedai had been known to become angry, very angry, with those who even mentioned the Black Ajah much less those who said they believed in its hidden existence. After this, with her will already weakened by that little childhood trick, Amalisa would be as clay in her hands. After one more blow.

"ðə blæk ədʒɑ ɪz ɹil, tʃaɪld. ɹil, ən hɪɹ wɪðɪn fæl dæɹəz wɔlz." əmælisə nɛl ðɛɹ, hɝ maʊθ hæŋɪŋ oʊpən. ðə blæk ədʒɑ. ɛɛs sədaɪ hu wɝ ɔlsoʊ dɑɹkfɹɛnz. ɔlmoʊst əz hɔɹəbəl tə lɝn ðə dɑɹk wʌn hɪmsɛlf wɔk fæl dæɹə kip. bʌt liɑnʒɹɪn wəd nɑt lɛɾ ʌp naʊ. "ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ðə hɔlz jə pæs, ə blæk sɪstɝ kəd bi. ðɪs aɪ swɛɹ. aɪ kænɑt tɛl jə wɪtʃ ðeɪ ɑɹ, bʌt maɪ pɹətɛkʃən jə kən hæv. ɪf ɪn ðə laɪt jə wɔk ən mi oʊbeɪ."

"The Black Ajah is real, child. Real, and here within Fal Dara's walls." Amalisa knelt there, her mouth hanging open. The Black Ajah. Aes Sedai who were also Darkfriends. Almost as horrible to learn the Dark One himself walked Fal Dara keep. But Liandrin would not let up now. "Any Aes Sedai in the halls you pass, a Black sister could be. This I swear. I cannot tell you which they are, but my protection you can have. If in the Light you walk and me obey."

"aɪ wɪl," əmælisə wɪspɝd hɔɹsli. "aɪ wɪl. pliz, liɑnʒɹɪn sədaɪ, pliz seɪ jəl pɹətɛk maɪ bɹʌðɝ, ən maɪ leɪɾiz. . . ."

"I will," Amalisa whispered hoarsely. "I will. Please, Liandrin Sedai, please say you will protect my brother, and my ladies. . . ."

"hu dɪzɝvz pɹətɛkʃən əl pɹətɛkt. kənsɝn jɝsɛlf wɪð jɝsɛlf, maɪ dɔɾɝ. ən θɪŋk oʊnli ʌv wʌɾ aɪ hæv kəmændəɾ ə ju. oʊnli ðæt. ðə feɪɾ ə ðə wɝld ɹaɪdz ɑn ðɪs, maɪ dɔɾɝ. ɔl ɛls jə mʌs fɝɡɛt."

"Who deserves protection I will protect. Concern yourself with yourself, my daughter. And think only of what I have commanded of you. Only that. The fate of the world rides on this, my daughter. All else you must forget."

"jɛs, liɑnʒɹɪn sədaɪ. jɛs. jɛs."

"Yes, Liandrin Sedai. Yes. Yes."

liɑnʒɹɪn tɝn ən kɹɔs ðə ɹum, nɑt lʊkɪŋ bæk əntɪl ʃi ɹitʃt ðə dɔɹ. əmælisə wɑz stɪl ɑn əɹ niz, stɪl wɑtʃɪŋ əɹ æŋkʃəsli. "ɹaɪz, maɪ leɪɾi əmælisə." liɑnʒɹɪn meɪɾ əɹ vɔɪs plɛzənt, wɪð oʊnli ə hɪn ə ðə mɑkɪŋ ʃi fɛlt. sɪstɝ, ɪndid! nɑt wʌn deɪ əz ə nɑvəs wəd ʃi læst. ən paʊɝ tə kəmænd ʃi hæz. "ɹaɪz." əmælisə stʃɹeɪɾənd ɪn sloʊ, stɪf dʒɝks, əz ɪf ʃi hæd bɪn baʊn hæn ən fʊt fəɹ aʊɝz. əz ʃi faɪnəli keɪm əpɹaɪt, liɑnʒɹɪn sɛd, ðə stil bæk ɪn fʊl stʃɹɛŋkθ, "æn ɪf jə feɪl ðə wɝld, ɪf jə feɪl mi, ðət ɹɛtʃɪd dɑɹkfɹɛn ɪn ðə dʌnʒən wɪl bi jəɹ ɛnvi."

Liandrin turned and crossed the room, not looking back until she reached the door. Amalisa was still on her knees, still watching her anxiously. "Rise, my Lady Amalisa." Liandrin made her voice pleasant, with only a hint of the mocking she felt. Sister, indeed! Not one day as a novice would she last. And power to command she has. "Rise." Amalisa straightened in slow, stiff jerks, as if she had been bound hand and foot for hours. As she finally came upright, Liandrin said, the steel back in full strength, "And if you fail the world, if you fail me, that wretched Darkfriend in the dungeon will be your envy."

fɹəm ðə lʊk ɑn əmælisəz feɪs, liɑnʒɹɪn dɪd nɑt θɪŋk feɪljɝ wəd kʌm fɹəm ɛni læk ʌv ɛfɝɾ ɑn əɹ pɑɹt.

From the look on Amalisa's face, Liandrin did not think failure would come from any lack of effort on her part.

pʊlɪŋ ðə dɔɹ ʃʌt bɪhaɪn hɝ, liɑnʒɹɪn sʌɾənli fɛlt ə pɹɪklɪŋ əkɹɔs əɹ skɪn. bɹɛθ kætʃɪŋ, ʃi wɝld əbaʊt, lʊkɪŋ ʌp ən daʊn ðə dɪmli lɪt hɔl. ɛmpti. ɪt wɑz fʊl naɪt bɪɑn ði æɹoʊslɪts. ðə hɔl wɑz ɛmpti, jɛt ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ðəɹ hæd bɪn aɪz ɑn hɝ. ðə veɪkən kɔɹəɾɝ, ʃæɾoʊi bɪtwin ðə læmps ɑn ðə wɔlz, mɑk hɝ. ʃi ʃɹʌɡd ənizəli, ðən stɑɹɾəd daʊn ðə hɔl dətɝmənədli. fænsiz teɪk mi. nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ.

Pulling the door shut behind her, Liandrin suddenly felt a prickling across her skin. Breath catching, she whirled about, looking up and down the dimly lit hall. Empty. It was full night beyond the arrowslits. The hall was empty, yet she was sure there had been eyes on her. The vacant corridor, shadowy between the lamps on the walls, mocked her. She shrugged uneasily, then started down the hall determinedly. Fancies take me. Nothing more.

fʊl naɪɾ ɔlɹɛɾi, ən ðəɹ wɑz mʌtʃ tə də bɪfɔɹ dɔn. hɝ ɔɹɾɝz hæd bɪn ɪksplɪsət.

Full night already, and there was much to do before dawn. Her orders had been explicit.

pɪtʃ-blæknəs kʌvɝd ðə dʌnʒənz wʌtɛvɝ ði aʊɝ, ənlɛs sʌmwʌn bɹɔɾ ɪn ə læntɝn, bʌt pdən feɪn sæɾ ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə hɪz kɑt, stɛɹɪŋ ɪndə ðə dɑɹk wɪð ə smaɪl ɑn ɪz feɪs. hi kəd hɪɹ ði ʌðɝ tu pɹɪznɝz ɡɹʌmbəlɪŋ ɪn ðɛɹ slip, mʌɾɝɪŋ ɪn naɪtmɛɹz. pdən feɪn wɑz weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ, sʌmθɪŋ i hæd bɪn əweɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ə lɔŋ taɪm. fəɹ tu lɔŋ. bʌt nɑt mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ.

Pitch-blackness covered the dungeons whatever the hour, unless someone brought in a lantern, but Padan Fain sat on the edge of his cot, staring into the dark with a smile on his face. He could hear the other two prisoners grumbling in their sleep, muttering in nightmares. Padan Fain was waiting for something, something he had been awaiting for a long time. For too long. But not much longer.

ðə dɔɹ tə ði aʊɾɝ ɡɑɹdʒɹum oʊpənd, spɪlɪŋ ɪn ə flʌɾ ə laɪt, dɑɹkli aʊtlaɪnɪŋ ə fɪɡjɝ ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ.

The door to the outer guardroom opened, spilling in a flood of light, darkly outlining a figure in the doorway.

feɪn stʊd. "ju! nɑɾ u aɪ ɪkspɛktəd." hi stʃɹɛtʃt wɪð ə kæʒəɑlnəs i dɪd nɑt fil. blʌd ɹeɪs θɹu hɪz veɪnz; hi θɔɾ i kəd lip oʊvɝ ðə kip ɪf i tʃɹaɪd. "sɝpɹaɪzəz fəɹ ɛvɹiwʌn, ɛ? wɛl, kʌm ɑn. ðə naɪts ɡɛɾɪŋ oʊld, ən aɪ wɑn səm slip sʌmtaɪm."

Fain stood. "You! Not who I expected." He stretched with a casualness he did not feel. Blood raced through his veins; he thought he could leap over the keep if he tried. "Surprises for everyone, eh? Well, come on. The night's getting old, and I want some sleep sometime."

əz ə læmp keɪm ɪndə ðə sɛl tʃeɪmbɝ, feɪn ɹeɪzd ɪz hɛd, ɡɹɪnɪŋ ət sʌmθɪŋ, ənsin jɛt fɛlt, bɪɑn ðə dʌnʒənz stoʊn silɪŋ. "ɪɾ ɪzən oʊvɝ jɛt," hi wɪspɝd. "ðə bæɾəlz nɛvɝ oʊvɝ."

As a lamp came into the cell chamber, Fain raised his head, grinning at something, unseen yet felt, beyond the dungeon's stone ceiling. "It isn't over yet," he whispered. "The battle's never over."


tʃæptɝ sɪks


CHAPTER 6

dɑɹk pɹɑfəsi


Dark Prophecy

ðə fɑɹmhaʊs dɔɹ ʃʊk ʌndɝ fjʊɹiəs bloʊz fɹəm aʊtsaɪd; ðə hɛvi bɑɹ əkɹɔs ðə dɔɹ dʒʌmpt ɪn ɪts bɹækəts. bɪɑn ðə wɪndoʊ nɛks tə ðə dɔɹ muv ðə hɛvi-mʌzəl sɪləwɛɾ ʌv ə tʃɹɑlɑk. ðəɹ wɝ wɪndoʊz ɛvɹiwɛɹ, ən mɔɹ ʃæɾoʊi ʃeɪps aʊtsaɪd. nɑt ʃæɾoʊi ɪnʌf, ðoʊ. ɹænd kəd stɪl meɪk əm aʊt.

The farmhouse door shook under furious blows from outside; the heavy bar across the door jumped in its brackets. Beyond the window next to the door moved the heavy-muzzled silhouette of a Trolloc. There were windows everywhere, and more shadowy shapes outside. Not shadowy enough, though. Rand could still make them out.

ðə wɪndoʊz, hi θɔt dɛspɝətli. hi bækt əweɪ fɹəm ðə dɔɹ, klʌtʃɪŋ ɪz sɔɹd bɪfɔɹ ɪm ɪn boʊθ hænz. ivən ɪf ðə dɔɹ hoʊlz, ðeɪ kən bɹeɪk ɪn ðə wɪndoʊz. waɪ ɑɹən ðeɪ tʃɹaɪɪŋ ðə wɪndoʊz?

The windows, he thought desperately. He backed away from the door, clutching his sword before him in both hands. Even if the door holds, they can break in the windows. Why aren't they trying the windows?

wɪð ə dɛfənɪŋ mətælɪk skɹitʃ, wʌn ə ðə bɹækəts pʊl pɑɹtli əweɪ fɹəm ðə dɔɹfɹeɪm, hæŋɪŋ lus ɑn neɪlz ɹɪpt ə fɪŋɡɝz wɪdθ aʊɾ ə ðə wʊd. ðə bɑɹ kwɪvɝd fɹəm ənʌðɝ bloʊ, ən ðə neɪlz skwild əɡɛn.

With a deafening metallic screech, one of the brackets pulled partly away from the doorframe, hanging loose on nails ripped a finger's width out of the wood. The bar quivered from another blow, and the nails squealed again.

"wi hæv tə stɑp ðɛm!" ɹænd ʃaʊɾəd. oʊnli wi kænt. wi kæn stɑp ðɛm. hi lʊkt ɝaʊn fəɹ ə weɪ tə ɹʌn, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli ðə wʌn dɔɹ. ðə ɹum wɑz ə bɑks. oʊnli wʌn dɔɹ, ən soʊ mɛni wɪndoʊz. "wi hæv tə də sʌmθɪŋ. sʌmθɪŋ!"

"We have to stop them!" Rand shouted. Only we can't. We can't stop them. He looked around for a way to run, but there was only the one door. The room was a box. Only one door, and so many windows. "We have to do something. Something!"

"ɪts tu leɪt," mæt sɛd. "doʊn jə ʌndɝstænd?" hɪz ɡɹɪn lʊkt ɑɾ ɑn ə blʌdləs peɪl feɪs, ən ðə hɪlt ʌv ə dæɡɝ stʊɾ aʊt fɹəm ɪz tʃɛst, ðə ɹubi ðət kæpt ɪt bleɪzɪŋ əz ɪf ɪt hɛl faɪɝ. ðə dʒɛm hæd mɔɹ laɪf ðən ɪz feɪs. "ɪts tu leɪt fəɹ əs tə tʃeɪnʒ ɛniθɪŋ."

"It's too late," Mat said. "Don't you understand?" His grin looked odd on a bloodless pale face, and the hilt of a dagger stood out from his chest, the ruby that capped it blazing as if it held fire. The gem had more life than his face. "It's too late for us to change anything."

"aɪv faɪnəli ɡɑɾən ɹɪɾ ə ðɛm," pɛɹɪn sɛd, læfɪŋ. blʌd stʃɹim daʊn ɪz feɪs laɪk ə flʌɾ ə tɪɹz fɹəm ɪz ɛmpti sɑkəts. hi hɛld aʊt ɹɛd hænz, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk ɹænd lʊk ət wʌɾ i hɛld. "aɪm fɹi, naʊ. ɪts oʊvɝ."

"I've finally gotten rid of them," Perrin said, laughing. Blood streamed down his face like a flood of tears from his empty sockets. He held out red hands, trying to make Rand look at what he held. "I'm free, now. It's over."

"ɪts nɛvɝ oʊvɝ, ælθɹ," pdən feɪn kɹaɪd, keɪpɝɪŋ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə flɔɹ. "ðə bæɾəlz nɛvɝ dʌn."

"It's never over, al'Thor," Padan Fain cried, capering in the middle of the floor. "The battle's never done."

ðə dɔɹ ɪksploʊɾəd ɪn splɪntɝz, ən ɹænd dʌkt əweɪ fɹəm ðə flaɪɪŋ ʃɑɹdz ʌv wʊd. tu ɹɛd-klæɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ stɛp θɹu, boʊɪŋ ðɛɹ mæstɝ ɪn. ə mæsk ðə kʌlɝ ə dʒɹaɪd blʌd kʌvɝd bælzəmənz feɪs, bʌt ɹænd kəd si ðə fleɪmz ə hɪz aɪz θɹu ði aɪɛslɪts; hi kəd hɪɹ ðə ɹɔɹɪŋ faɪɝz ə bælzəmənz maʊθ.

The door exploded in splinters, and Rand ducked away from the flying shards of wood. Two red-clad Aes Sedai stepped through, bowing their master in. A mask the color of dried blood covered Ba'alzamon's face, but Rand could see the flames of his eyes through the eyeslits; he could hear the roaring fires of Ba'alzamon's mouth.

"ɪɾ ɪz nɑt jɛt dʌn bɪtwin ʌs, ælθɹ," bælzəmən sɛd, ən i ən feɪn spoʊk təɡɛðɝ əz wʌn, "fɔɹ ju, ðə bæɾəl ɪz nɛvɝ dʌn."

"It is not yet done between us, al'Thor," Ba'alzamon said, and he and Fain spoke together as one, "For you, the battle is never done."

wɪð ə stʃɹæŋɡəld ɡæsp ɹænd sæɾ ʌp ɑn ðə flɔɹ, klɔɪŋ ɪz weɪ əweɪk. ɪt simd i kəd stɪl hɪɹ feɪnz vɔɪs, əz ʃɑɹp əz ɪf ðə pɛdlɝ wɝ stændɪŋ bɪsaɪd hɪm. ɪts nɛvɝ oʊvɝ. ðə bæɾəlz nɛvɝ dʌn.

With a strangled gasp Rand sat up on the floor, clawing his way awake. It seemed he could still hear Fain's voice, as sharp as if the peddler were standing beside him. It's never over. The battle's never done.

blɪɹi-aɪd, hi lʊkt ɝaʊn tə kənvɪns hɪmsɛlf ðəɾ i wɑz stɪl hɪɾən əweɪ wɛɹ ɛɡwin hæd lɛf hɪm, bɛɾəd daʊn ɑn ə pæləɾ ɪn ə kɔɹnɝ ə hɝ ɹum. ðə dɪm laɪɾ ʌv ə sɪŋɡəl læmp səfjuz ðə ɹum, ən i wɑz sɝpɹaɪz tə si nɪneɪiv, nɪɾɪŋ ɪn ə ɹɑkɪŋ tʃɛɹ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə loʊn bɛd, ɪts kʌvɝz stɪl ɪn pleɪs. ɪt wɑz naɪɾ aʊtsaɪd.

Bleary-eyed, he looked around to convince himself that he was still hidden away where Egwene had left him, bedded down on a pallet in a corner of her room. The dim light of a single lamp suffused the room, and he was surprised to see Nynaeve, knitting in a rocking chair on the other side of the lone bed, its covers still in place. It was night outside.

dɑɹk-aɪɾ ən slɛndɝ, nɪneɪiv wɔɹ əɹ hɛɹ ɪn ə fæt bɹeɪd, pʊld oʊvɝ wʌn ʃoʊldɝ ən hæŋɪŋ ɔlmoʊs tə hɝ weɪst. ʃi hæd nɑt ɡɪvən ʌp ɑn hoʊm. hɝ feɪs wɑz kɑm, ən ʃi simd əwɛɹ ə nʌθɪŋ ɪksɛpt əɹ nɪɾɪŋ əz ʃi ɹɑk dʒɛnli. ðə stɛɾi klɪk-klɪk ə hɝ nɪɾɪŋ niɾəlz wɑz ði oʊnli saʊnd. ðə ɹʌɡ saɪləns ðə ɹɑkɪŋ tʃɛɹ.

Dark-eyed and slender, Nynaeve wore her hair in a fat braid, pulled over one shoulder and hanging almost to her waist. She had not given up on home. Her face was calm, and she seemed aware of nothing except her knitting as she rocked gently. The steady click-click of her knitting needles was the only sound. The rug silenced the rocking chair.

ðəɹ hæd bɪn naɪts ə leɪt wən i hæd wɪʃt fəɹ ə kɑɹpəɾ ɑn ðə koʊl stoʊn flɔɹ ə hɪz ɹum, bʌɾ ɪn ʃaɪnɝ mɛnz ɹumz wɝ ɔlweɪz bɛɹ ən stɑɹk. ðə wɔlz hɪɹ hæd tu tæpəstʃɹiz, maʊntən sinz wɪð wɔɾɝfɔlz, ən flaʊɝ-ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd kɝɾənz əlɔŋsaɪd ði æɹoʊslɪts. kʌt flaʊɝz, waɪt mɔɹnɪŋstɑɹz, stʊɾ ɪn ə flæt, ɹaʊn veɪs ɑn ðə teɪbəl baɪ ðə bɛd, ən mɔɹ nɑɾəd ɪn ɡleɪzd waɪt skɑnsɪz ɑn ðə wɔlz. ə tɔl mɪɹɝ stʊɾ ɪn ə kɔɹnɝ, ən ənʌðɝ hʌŋ oʊvɝ ðə wɑʃstænd, wɪð ɪts blu-stʃɹaɪpt pɪtʃɝ ən boʊl. hi wʌndɝd waɪ ɛɡwin niɾəd tu mɪɹɝz; ðəɹ wɑz nʌn ɪn ɪz ɹum, ən i dɪd nɑt mɪs ɪt. ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli wʌn læmp lɪt, bʌt fɔɹ mɔɹ stʊɾ ɝaʊn ðə ɹum, wɪtʃ wɑz nɪɹli əz lɑɹdʒ əz ðə wʌn i ʃɛɹd wɪð mæt ən pɛɹɪn. ɛɡwin hæɾ ɪɾ əloʊn.

There had been nights of late when he had wished for a carpet on the cold stone floor of his room, but in Shienar men's rooms were always bare and stark. The walls here had two tapestries, mountain scenes with waterfalls, and flower-embroidered curtains alongside the arrowslits. Cut flowers, white morningstars, stood in a flat, round vase on the table by the bed, and more nodded in glazed white sconces on the walls. A tall mirror stood in a corner, and another hung over the washstand, with its blue-striped pitcher and bowl. He wondered why Egwene needed two mirrors; there was none in his room, and he did not miss it. There was only one lamp lit, but four more stood around the room, which was nearly as large as the one he shared with Mat and Perrin. Egwene had it alone.

wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ ʌp, nɪneɪiv sɛd, "ɪf jə slip ɪn ði æftɝnun, jə kæn ɪkspɛk tə slip ət naɪt."

Without looking up, Nynaeve said, "If you sleep in the afternoon, you can't expect to sleep at night."

hi fɹaʊnd, ðoʊ ʃi kəd nɑt si ɪt. ət list, hi θɔt ʃi kəd nɑt. ʃi wɑz oʊnli ə fju jɪɹz oʊldɝ ðən hi, bʌt biɪŋ wɪzdəm æɾəd fɪfti jɪɹz ʌv əθɔɹəɾi. "aɪ niɾəd ə pleɪs tə haɪd, ən aɪ wɑz taɪɝd," hi sɛd, ðən kwɪkli æɾəd, "aɪ dɪdn dʒʌs kʌm hɪɹ. ɛɡwin ɪnvaɪɾəd mi ɪndə ðə wɪmənz əpɑɹtməns."

He frowned, though she could not see it. At least, he thought she could not. She was only a few years older than he, but being Wisdom added fifty years of authority. "I needed a place to hide, and I was tired," he said, then quickly added, "I didn't just come here. Egwene invited me into the women's apartments."

nɪneɪiv loʊɝɾ əɹ nɪɾɪŋ ən ɡeɪv ɪm ən əmjuz smaɪl. ʃi wɑz ə pɹɪɾi wʊmən. ðət wɑz sʌmθɪŋ i wəd nɛvɝ əv noʊɾəst bæk hoʊm; wʌn dʒʌs dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ʌv ə wɪzdəm ðət weɪ. "ðə laɪt hɛlp mi, ɹænd, jə ɑɹ bɪkʌmɪŋ mɔɹ ʃaɪnɝən ɛvɹi deɪ. ɪnvaɪɾəd ɪndə ðə wɪmənz əpɑɹtməns, ɪndid." ʃi snɪft. "ɛni deɪ naʊ, jəl stɑɹt tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt jəɹ ɑnɝ, ən æskɪŋ pis tə feɪvɝ jəɹ sɔɹd." hi kʌlɝd, ən hoʊpt ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊɾəs ɪn ðə dɪm laɪt. ʃi aɪɾ ɪz sɔɹd, ɪts hɪl stɪkɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə lɔŋ bʌndəl bɪsaɪɾ ɪm ɑn ðə flɔɹ. hi nu ʃi dɪd nɑɾ əpɹuv ə ðə sɔɹd, ʌv ɛni sɔɹd, bʌt ʃi sɛd nʌθɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt fəɹ wʌns. "ɛɡwin toʊl mi waɪ jə niɾ ə pleɪs tə haɪd. doʊnt wɝi. wɪl kip jə hɪɾən fɹəm ði æmɪɝlɪn, əɹ fɹəm ɛni ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɪf ðəɾ ɪz wʌt jə wɑnt."

Nynaeve lowered her knitting and gave him an amused smile. She was a pretty woman. That was something he would never have noticed back home; one just did not think of a Wisdom that way. "The Light help me, Rand, you are becoming more Shienaran every day. Invited into the women's apartments, indeed." She sniffed. "Any day now, you'll start talking about your honor, and asking peace to favor your sword." He colored, and hoped she did not notice in the dim light. She eyed his sword, its hilt sticking out of the long bundle beside him on the floor. He knew she did not approve of the sword, of any sword, but she said nothing about it for once. "Egwene told me why you need a place to hide. Don't worry. We will keep you hidden from the Amyrlin, or from any other Aes Sedai, if that is what you want."

ʃi mɛɾ ɪz aɪz ən dʒɝk hɝz əweɪ, bʌt nɑt bɪfɔɹ i sɔ hɝ ʌnizinəs. hɝ daʊt. ðæts ɹaɪt, aɪ kən tʃænəl ðə paʊɝ. ə mæn wildɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ! jə ɔt tə bi hɛlpɪŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hʌn mi daʊn ən dʒɛntəl mi.

She met his eyes and jerked hers away, but not before he saw her uneasiness. Her doubt. That's right, I can channel the Power. A man wielding the One Power! You ought to be helping the Aes Sedai hunt me down and gentle me.

skaʊlɪŋ, hi stʃɹeɪɾənd ðə lɛðɝ dʒɝkɪn ɛɡwin hæd faʊn fəɹ ɪm ən twɪstəɾ ɝaʊn soʊ hi kəd lin bæk əɡɛns ðə wɔl. "æz sun əz aɪ kæn, əl haɪɾ ɪn ə kɑɹt, əɹ snik aʊt. jə woʊn əv tə haɪd mi lɔŋ." nɪneɪiv dɪd nɑt seɪ ɛniθɪŋ; ʃi fɪkst ɑn əɹ nɪɾɪŋ, meɪkɪŋ ən æŋɡɹi saʊnd wən ʃi dʒɹɑpt ə stɪtʃ. "wɛɹ ɪz ɛɡwin?"

Scowling, he straightened the leather jerkin Egwene had found for him and twisted around so he could lean back against the wall. "As soon as I can, I will hide in a cart, or sneak out. You won't have to hide me long." Nynaeve did not say anything; she fixed on her knitting, making an angry sound when she dropped a stitch. "Where is Egwene?"

ʃi lɛt ðə nɪɾɪŋ fɔl ɑntu hɝ læp. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ waɪ aɪm ivən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tənaɪt. aɪ kæn kip tʃɹæk ə maɪ stɪtʃɪz fəɹ səm ɹizən. ʃiz ɡɔn daʊn tə si pdən feɪn. ʃi θɪŋks siɪŋ feɪsəz i noʊz maɪt hɛlp hɪm."

She let the knitting fall onto her lap. "I don't know why I am even trying tonight. I can't keep track of my stitches for some reason. She has gone down to see Padan Fain. She thinks seeing faces he knows might help him."

"maɪn sɝɾənli dɪd nɑt. ʃi ɔt tə steɪ əweɪ fɹəm hɪm. hiz deɪnʒɝəs."

"Mine certainly did not. She ought to stay away from him. He's dangerous."

"ʃi wɑns tə hɛlp hɪm," nɪneɪiv sɛd kɑmli. "ɹɪmɛmbɝ, ʃi wɑz tʃɹeɪnɪŋ tə bi maɪ əsɪstənt, ən biɪŋ ə wɪzdəm ɪz nɑɾ ɔl pɹɪdɪktɪŋ ðə wɛðɝ. hilɪŋ ɪz pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt, tu. ɛɡwin əz ðə dɪzaɪɝ tə hil, ðə nid tə. ən ɪf pdən feɪn ɪz soʊ deɪnʒɝəs, mɔɪɹeɪn wʊɾə sɛd sʌmθɪŋ."

"She wants to help him," Nynaeve said calmly. "Remember, she was training to be my assistant, and being a Wisdom is not all predicting the weather. Healing is part of it, too. Egwene has the desire to heal, the need to. And if Padan Fain is so dangerous, Moiraine would have said something."

hi bɑɹkt ə læf. "ju dɪdn æsk hɝ. ɛɡwin ədmɪɾəd ɪt, ən aɪ kən dʒʌst si jə æskɪŋ pɝmɪʃən fəɹ ɛniθɪŋ." hɝ ɹeɪzd aɪbɹaʊ waɪp ðə læf ɔf ɪz feɪs. hi ɹəfjuz tə əpɑlədʒaɪz, ðoʊ. ðeɪ wɝ ə lɔŋ weɪ fɹəm hoʊm, ən i dɪd nɑt si haʊ ʃi kəd ɡoʊ ɑn biɪŋ wɪzdəm ʌv ɛmənz fild ɪf ʃi wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn. "hæv ðeɪ stɑɹɾəd tə sɝtʃ fəɹ mi, jɛt? ɛɡwin ɪz nɑt ʃʊɹ ðeɪ wɪl, bʌt læn sɛz ði æmɪɝlɪn siɾ ɪz hɪɹ kəz ə mi, ən aɪ θɪŋk əl teɪk ɪz əpɪnjən oʊvɝ hɝz."

He barked a laugh. "You didn't ask her. Egwene admitted it, and I can just see you asking permission for anything." Her raised eyebrow wiped the laugh off his face. He refused to apologize, though. They were a long way from home, and he did not see how she could go on being Wisdom of Emond's Field if she was going to Tar Valon. "Have they started to search for me, yet? Egwene is not sure they will, but Lan says the Amyrlin Seat is here because of me, and I think I'll take his opinion over hers."

fəɹ ə moʊmənt nɪneɪiv dɪd nɑɾ ænsɝ. ɪnstɛd ʃi fʌst wɪð əɹ sknz ə jɑɹn. faɪnəli ʃi sɛd, "aɪ æm nɑt ʃʊɹ. wʌn ə ðə sɝvɪŋ wɪmən keɪm ə lɪɾəl waɪl əɡoʊ. tə tɝn daʊn ðə bɛd, ʃi sɛd. əz ɪf ɛɡwin wəd bi gɑnə slip ɔlɹɛɾi, wɪð ðə fis fəɹ ði æmɪɝlɪn tənaɪt. aɪ sɛn əɹ əweɪ; ʃi dɪdn si ju."

For a moment Nynaeve did not answer. Instead she fussed with her skeins of yarn. Finally she said, "I am not sure. One of the serving women came a little while ago. To turn down the bed, she said. As if Egwene would be going to sleep already, with the feast for the Amyrlin tonight. I sent her away; she didn't see you."

"noʊbɑdi tɝnz jəɹ bɛd daʊn fəɹ jə ɪn ðə mɛnz kɔɹɾɝz." ʃi ɡeɪv ɪm ə lɛvəl lʊk, wʌn ðət wʊɾə sɛɾ ɪm stæmɝɪŋ ə jɪɹ əɡoʊ. hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ðeɪ wʊdn juz ðə meɪdz tə lʊk fəɹ mi, nɪneɪiv."

"Nobody turns your bed down for you in the men's quarters." She gave him a level look, one that would have set him stammering a year ago. He shook his head. "They wouldn't use the maids to look for me, Nynaeve."

"wɛn aɪ wɛn tə ðə bʌɾɝi fəɹ ə kʌp ə mɪlk ɝliɝ, ðəɹ wɝ tu mɛni wɪmən ɪn ðə hɔlz. ðoʊz u ɑɹ ətɛndɪŋ ðə fist ʃʊɾə bɪn ɡɛɾɪŋ dʒɹɛst, ən ði ʌðɝz ʃəɾ iðɝ əv bɪn hɛlpɪŋ əm əɹ ɡɛɾɪŋ ɹɛɾi tə sɝv, əɹ tə. . . ." ʃi fɹaʊnd wɝidli. "ðɛɹz mɔɹ ðən ɪnʌf wɝk fəɹ ɛvɹibɑɾi wɪð ði æmɪɝlɪn hɪɹ. ən ðeɪ wɝ nɑt dʒʌs hɪɹ ɪn ðə wɪmənz əpɑɹtməns. aɪ sɔ ðə leɪɾi əmælisə hɝsɛlf kʌmɪŋ aʊɾ ʌv ə stɔɹɹum nɪɹ ðə bʌɾɝi wɪð əɹ feɪs ɔl oʊvɝ dʌst."

"When I went to the buttery for a cup of milk earlier, there were too many women in the halls. Those who are attending the feast should have been getting dressed, and the others should either have been helping them or getting ready to serve, or to. . . ." She frowned worriedly. "There's more than enough work for everybody with the Amyrlin here. And they were not just here in the women's apartments. I saw the Lady Amalisa herself coming out of a storeroom near the buttery with her face all over dust."

"ðæts ɹɪdɪkjələs. waɪ wəd ʃi bi pɑɹɾ ʌv ə sɝtʃ? əɹ ɛni ʌv ðə wɪmən, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ. ðeɪd bi juzɪŋ lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝz soʊlʒɝz, ən ðə wɔɹɾɝz. ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðeɪ mʌs dʒʌs bi duɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ fəɹ ðə fist. bɝn mi ɪf aɪ noʊ wʌɾ ə ʃaɪnɝən fis teɪks."

"That's ridiculous. Why would she be part of a search? Or any of the women, for that matter. They'd be using Lord Agelmar's soldiers, and the Warders. And the Aes Sedai. They must just be doing something for the feast. Burn me if I know what a Shienaran feast takes."

"ju ɑɹ ə wʊlhɛd, səmtaɪmz, ɹænd. ðə mɛn aɪ sɔ dɪdnt noʊ wʌt ðə wɪmən wɝ duɪŋ iðɝ. aɪ hɝd səm ə ðɛm kəmpleɪnɪŋ əbaʊt hævɪŋ tə də ɔl ðə wɝk baɪ ðɛmsɛlvz. aɪ noʊ ɪt meɪks noʊ sɛns ðət ðeɪ wɝ lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ju. nʌn ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sim tə bi teɪkɪŋ ɛni ɪntʃɹəst. bʌɾ əmælisə wɑz nɑt ɹɛɾiɪŋ hɝsɛlf fəɹ ðə fis baɪ dɝɾiɪŋ əɹ dʒɹɛs ɪn ə stɔɹɹum. ðeɪ wɝ lʊkɪŋ fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ, sʌmθɪŋ ɪmpɔɹɾənt. ivən ɪf ʃi bɪɡæn ɹaɪɾ æftɝ aɪ sɔ hɝ, ʃi wəd bɛɹli hæv taɪm tə beɪð ən tʃeɪnʒ. spikɪŋ ʌv wɪtʃ, ɪf ɛɡwin dʌzn kʌm bæk sun, ʃɪl əv tə tʃuz bɪtwin tʃeɪnʒɪŋ ən biɪŋ leɪt."

"You are a woolhead, sometimes, Rand. The men I saw didn't know what the women were doing either. I heard some of them complaining about having to do all the work by themselves. I know it makes no sense that they were looking for you. None of the Aes Sedai seemed to be taking any interest. But Amalisa was not readying herself for the feast by dirtying her dress in a storeroom. They were looking for something, something important. Even if she began right after I saw her, she would barely have time to bathe and change. Speaking of which, if Egwene doesn't come back soon, she'll have to choose between changing and being late."

fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm, hi ɹilaɪz ðət nɪneɪiv wɑz nɑt wɛɹɪŋ ðə tu ɹɪvɝz wʊlənz i wɑz juz tə. hɝ dʒɹɛs wɑz peɪl blu sɪlk, ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɪn snoʊdʒɹɑp blɑsəmz ɝaʊn ðə nɛk ən daʊn ðə slivz. itʃ blɑsəm sɛntɝɾ ɑn ə smɔl pɝl, ən əɹ bɛlt wɑz tuld ɪn sɪlvɝ, wɪð ə sɪlvɝ bʌkəl sɛt wɪð pɝlz. hi hæd nɛvɝ sin əɹ ɪn ɛniθɪŋ laɪk ðæt. ivən fistdeɪ kloʊðz bæk hoʊm maɪt nɑt mætʃ ɪt.

For the first time, he realized that Nynaeve was not wearing the Two Rivers woolens he was used to. Her dress was pale blue silk, embroidered in snowdrop blossoms around the neck and down the sleeves. Each blossom centered on a small pearl, and her belt was tooled in silver, with a silver buckle set with pearls. He had never seen her in anything like that. Even feastday clothes back home might not match it.

"jɔɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə ðə fist?"

"You're going to the feast?"

"ʌv kɔɹs. ivən ɪf mɔɪɹeɪn hæd nɑt sɛɾ aɪ ʃʊd, aɪ wəd nɛvɝ lɛɾ əɹ θɪŋk aɪ wɑz. . . ." hɝ aɪz lɪɾ ʌp fɪɹsli fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ən i nu wʌt ʃi mɛnt. nɪneɪiv wəd nɛvɝ lɛɾ ɛniwʌn θɪŋk ʃi wɑz əfɹeɪd, ivən ɪf ʃi wɑz. sɝɾənli nɑt mɔɪɹeɪn, ən ɪspɛʃli nɑt læn. hi hoʊpt ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ hi wɑz əwɛɹ ə hɝ filɪŋz fəɹ ðə wɔɹɾɝ.

"Of course. Even if Moiraine had not said I should, I would never let her think I was. . . ." Her eyes lit up fiercely for a moment, and he knew what she meant. Nynaeve would never let anyone think she was afraid, even if she was. Certainly not Moiraine, and especially not Lan. He hoped she did not know he was aware of her feelings for the Warder.

æftɝ ə moʊmən əɹ ɡeɪz sɔfən əz ɪt fɛl ɑn ðə sliv ə hɝ dʒɹɛs. "ðə leɪɾi əmælisə ɡeɪv mi ðɪs," ʃi sɛd soʊ sɔfli hi wʌndɝɾ ɪf ʃi wɑz spikɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf. ʃi stʃɹoʊk ðə sɪlk wɪð əɹ fɪŋɡɝz, aʊtlaɪnɪŋ ði ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd flaʊɝz, smaɪlɪŋ, lɔst ɪn θɔt.

After a moment her gaze softened as it fell on the sleeve of her dress. "The Lady Amalisa gave me this," she said so softly he wondered if she was speaking to herself. She stroked the silk with her fingers, outlining the embroidered flowers, smiling, lost in thought.

"ɪts vɛɹi pɹɪɾi ɑn ju, nɪneɪiv. jəɹ pɹɪɾi tənaɪt." hi wɪnst əz sun əz i sɛɾ ɪt. ɛni wɪzdəm wɑz tʌtʃi əbaʊɾ əɹ əθɔɹəɾi, bʌt nɪneɪiv wɑz tʌtʃiɝ ðən moʊst. ðə wɪmənz sɝkəl bæk hoʊm hæɾ ɔlweɪz lʊkt oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ kəz ʃi wɑz jʌŋ, ən meɪbi kəz ʃi wɑz pɹɪɾi, ən əɹ faɪts wɪð ðə meɪɝ ən ðə vɪlədʒ kaʊnsəl hæd bɪn ðə stʌf ə stɔɹiz.

"It's very pretty on you, Nynaeve. You're pretty tonight." He winced as soon as he said it. Any Wisdom was touchy about her authority, but Nynaeve was touchier than most. The Women's Circle back home had always looked over her shoulder because she was young, and maybe because she was pretty, and her fights with the Mayor and the Village Council had been the stuff of stories.

ʃi dʒɝkt əɹ hæn əweɪ fɹəm ði ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi ən ɡlɛɹɾ ət hɪm, bɹaʊz loʊɝɪŋ. hi spoʊk kwɪkli tə fɔɹstɔl hɝ.

She jerked her hand away from the embroidery and glared at him, brows lowering. He spoke quickly to forestall her.

"ðeɪ kæn kip ðə ɡeɪts bɑɹd fɝɛvɝ. wʌns ðeɪ ɑɹ oʊpənd, əl bi ɡɔn, ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪl nɛvɝ faɪn mi. pɛɹɪn sɛz ðəɹ ɑɹ pleɪsəz ɪn ðə blæk hɪlz ən ðə kæɹələn ɡɹæs jə kən ɡoʊ fəɹ deɪz wɪθaʊt siɪŋ ə soʊl. meɪbi - meɪbi aɪ kən fɪɡjɝ aʊt wʌt tə də əbaʊt. . . ." hi ʃɹʌɡd ənkʌmftəbli. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid tə seɪ ɪt, nɑt tə hɝ. "æn ɪf aɪ kænt, ðɛɹəl bi noʊ wʌn tə hɝt."

"They can't keep the gates barred forever. Once they are opened, I will be gone, and the Aes Sedai will never find me. Perrin says there are places in the Black Hills and the Caralain Grass you can go for days without seeing a soul. Maybe - maybe I can figure out what to do about. . . ." He shrugged uncomfortably. There was no need to say it, not to her. "And if I can't, there'll be no one to hurt."

nɪneɪiv wɑz saɪlən fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ðən ʃi sɛd sloʊli, "aɪ æm nɑt soʊ ʃʊɹ, ɹænd. aɪ kæn seɪ jə lʊk laɪk mɔɹ ðən ənʌðɝ vɪlədʒ bɔɪ tə mi, bʌt mɔɪɹeɪn ɪnsɪsts jə ɑɹ tɑvɝən, ən aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ʃi bɪlivz ðə wil ɪz fɪnɪʃt wɪð ju. ðə dɑɹk wʌn simz - "

Nynaeve was silent for a moment, then she said slowly, "I am not so sure, Rand. I can't say you look like more than another village boy to me, but Moiraine insists you are ta'veren, and I don't think she believes the Wheel is finished with you. The Dark One seems - "

"ʃeɪtɑn ɪz dɛd," hi sɛd hɑɹʃli, ən əbɹʌpli ðə ɹum sim tə lɝtʃ. hi ɡɹæbd ɪz hɛɾ əz weɪvz ə dɪzinəs slɑʃt θɹu hɪm.

"Shai'tan is dead," he said harshly, and abruptly the room seemed to lurch. He grabbed his head as waves of dizziness sloshed through him.

"ju ful! jə pjʊɹ, blaɪnd, ɪɾiɑtɪk ful! neɪmɪŋ ðə dɑɹk wʌn, bɹɪŋɪŋ ɪz ətɛnʃən daʊn ɑn ju! doʊn juv ɪnʌf tʃɹʌbəl?"

"You fool! You pure, blind, idiotic fool! Naming the Dark One, bringing his attention down on you! Don't you have enough trouble?"

"hiz dɛd," ɹænd mʌɾɝd, ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz hɛd. hi swɑloʊd. ðə dɪzinəs wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi feɪɾɪŋ. "ɔl ɹaɪt, ɔl ɹaɪt. bælzəmən, ɪf jə wɑnt. bʌt hiz dɛd; aɪ sɔ hɪm daɪ, sɔ hɪm bɝn."

"He's dead," Rand muttered, rubbing his head. He swallowed. The dizziness was already fading. "All right, all right. Ba'alzamon, if you want. But he's dead; I saw him die, saw him burn."

"æn aɪ wɑznt wɑtʃɪŋ jə wən ðə dɑɹk wʌnz aɪ fɛl ɑn jə dʒʌs naʊ? doʊn tɛl mi jə fɛl nʌθɪŋ, əɹ əl bɑks jəɹ ɪɹz; aɪ sɔ jəɹ feɪs."

"And I wasn't watching you when the Dark One's eye fell on you just now? Don't tell me you felt nothing, or I'll box your ears; I saw your face."

"hiz dɛd," ɹænd ɪnsɪstəd. ði ənsin wɑtʃɝ flæʃt θɹu hɪz hɛd, ən ðə wɪn ɑn ðə taʊɝ tɑp. hi ʃɪvɝd. "stʃɹeɪnʒ θɪŋz hæpən ðɪs kloʊs tə ðə blaɪt."

"He's dead," Rand insisted. The unseen watcher flashed through his head, and the wind on the tower top. He shivered. "Strange things happen this close to the Blight."

"ju ɑɹ ə ful, ɹænd ælθɹ." ʃi ʃʊk ə fɪst ət hɪm. "aɪ wəd bɑks jəɹ ɪɹz fəɹ jə ɪf aɪ θɔɾ ɪt wəd nɑk ɛni sɛns - "

"You are a fool, Rand al'Thor." She shook a fist at him. "I would box your ears for you if I thought it would knock any sense - "

ðə ɹɛst ə hɝ wɝdz wɝ swɑloʊɾ əz bɛlz kɹæʃt aʊt ɹɪŋɪŋ ɔl oʊvɝ ðə kip.

The rest of her words were swallowed as bells crashed out ringing all over the keep.

hi baʊndəd tə hɪz fit. "ðæts ən əlɑɹm! ðəɹ sɝtʃɪŋ. . . ." neɪm ðə dɑɹk wʌn, ən ɪz ivəl kʌmz daʊn ɑn ju.

He bounded to his feet. "That's an alarm! They're searching. . . ." Name the Dark One, and his evil comes down on you.

nɪneɪiv stʊd mɔɹ sloʊli, ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛɾ ənizəli. "noʊ, aɪ doʊn θɪŋk soʊ. ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹ sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ ju, ɔl ðə bɛlz də ɪz wɔɹn ju. noʊ, ɪf ɪts ən əlɑɹm, ɪts nɑt fəɹ ju."

Nynaeve stood more slowly, shaking her head uneasily. "No, I don't think so. If they are searching for you, all the bells do is warn you. No, if it's an alarm, it is not for you."

"ðɛn wʌt?" hi hɝid tə ðə nɪɹəst æɹoʊslɪɾ ən pɪɹɾ aʊt.

"Then what?" He hurried to the nearest arrowslit and peered out.

laɪts dɑɹɾɪd θɹu ðə naɪt-kloʊkt kip laɪk faɪɝəfliz, læmps ən tɔɹtʃɪz dæʃɪŋ hɪɹ ən ðɛɹ. səm wɛn tə ði aʊɾɝ wɔlz ən taʊɝz, bʌt moʊst ə ðoʊz ðəɾ i kəd si mɪl θɹu ðə ɡɑɹɾən bɪloʊ ən ðə wʌn kɔɹtʃjɑɹɾ i kəd dʒʌst ɡlɪmps pɑɹɾ ʌv. wʌtɛvɝ hæd kɑz ði əlɑɹm wɑz ɪnsaɪd ðə kip. ðə bɛlz fɛl saɪlənt, ənmæskɪŋ ðə ʃaʊts ə mɛn, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt meɪk aʊt wʌt ðeɪ wɝ kɔlɪŋ.
