Lights darted through the night-cloaked keep like fireflies, lamps and torches dashing here and there. Some went to the outer walls and towers, but most of those that he could see milled through the garden below and the one courtyard he could just glimpse part of. Whatever had caused the alarm was inside the keep. The bells fell silent, unmasking the shouts of men, but he could not make out what they were calling.

ɪf ɪɾ ɪzən fəɹ mi. . . . "ɛɡwin," hi sɛd sʌɾənli. ɪf hiz stɪl əlaɪv, ɪf ðɛɹz ɛni ivəl, ɪts səpoʊz tə kʌm tə mi.

If it isn't for me. . . . "Egwene," he said suddenly. If he's still alive, if there's any evil, it's supposed to come to me.

nɪneɪiv tɝn fɹəm lʊkɪŋ θɹu ənʌðɝ æɹoʊslɪt. "wʌt?"

Nynaeve turned from looking through another arrowslit. "What?"

"ɛɡwin." hi kɹɔs ðə ɹum ɪn kwɪk stʃɹaɪdz ən snætʃt ɪz sɔɹɾ ən skæbɝd fɹi ʌv ðə bʌndəl. laɪt, ɪts səpoʊz tə hɝt mi, nɑt hɝ. "ʃiz ɪn ðə dʌnʒən wɪð feɪn. wʌɾ ɪf hiz lus sʌmhaʊ?"

"Egwene." He crossed the room in quick strides and snatched his sword and scabbard free of the bundle. Light, it's supposed to hurt me, not her. "She's in the dungeon with Fain. What if he's loose somehow?"

ʃi kɑɾ ɪm ət ðə dɔɹ, ɡɹæbɪŋ ɪz ɑɹm. ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əz tɔl əz ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, bʌt ʃi hɛld ɑn laɪk aɪɝn. "doʊn bi ə wɝs ɡoʊt-bɹeɪn ful ðən juv ɔlɹɛɾi bɪn, ɹænd ælθɹ. ivən ɪf ðɪs dʌzn əv ɛniθɪŋ tə də wɪð ju, ðə wɪmən ɑɹ lʊkɪŋ fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ! laɪt, mæn, ðɪs ɪz ðə wɪmənz əpɑɹtməns. ðəɹ wɪl bi ɛɛs sədaɪ aʊt ðəɹ ɪn ðə hɔlz, laɪkli əz nɑt. ɛɡwin wɪl bi ɔl ɹaɪt. ʃi wɑz gɑnə teɪk mæt ən pɛɹɪn wɪð hɝ. ivən ɪf ʃi mɛt tʃɹʌbəl, ðeɪ wəd lʊk æftɝ hɝ."

She caught him at the door, grabbing his arm. She was not as tall as his shoulder, but she held on like iron. "Don't be a worse goat-brained fool than you've already been, Rand al'Thor. Even if this doesn't have anything to do with you, the women are looking for something! Light, man, this is the women's apartments. There will be Aes Sedai out there in the halls, likely as not. Egwene will be all right. She was going to take Mat and Perrin with her. Even if she met trouble, they would look after her."

"wʌɾ ɪf ʃi kʊdn faɪn ðɛm, nɪneɪiv? ɛɡwin wəd nɛvɝ lɛt ðət stɑp hɝ. ʃi wəd ɡoʊ əloʊn, ðə seɪm əz ju, ən jə noʊ ɪt. laɪt, aɪ toʊld əɹ feɪn ɪz deɪnʒɝəs! bɝn mi, aɪ toʊl hɝ!" pʊlɪŋ fɹi, hi dʒɝkt oʊpən ðə dɔɹ ən dæʃt aʊt. laɪt bɝn mi, ɪts səpoʊz tə hɝt mi!

"What if she couldn't find them, Nynaeve? Egwene would never let that stop her. She would go alone, the same as you, and you know it. Light, I told her Fain is dangerous! Burn me, I told her!" Pulling free, he jerked open the door and dashed out. Light burn me, it's supposed to hurt me!

ə wʊmən skɹimd ət ðə saɪɾ ə hɪm, ɪn ə leɪbɝɝz kɔɹs ʃɝɾ ən dʒɝkɪn wɪð ə sɔɹɾ ɪn ɪz hænd. ivən ɪnvaɪɾəd, mɛn dɪd nɑt ɡoʊ ɑɹmd ɪn ðə wɪmənz əpɑɹtməns ənlɛs ðə kip wɑz ʌndɝ ətæk. wɪmən fɪl ðə kɔɹəɾɝ, sɝvɪŋ wɪmən ɪn ðə blæk-ænd-ɡoʊld, leɪɾiz ə ðə kip ɪn sɪlks ən leɪsəz, wɪmən ɪn ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ʃɔlz wɪð lɔŋ fɹɪnʒɪz, ɔl tɔkɪŋ laʊdli ət ðə seɪm taɪm, ɔl dɪmændɪŋ tə noʊ wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ. kɹaɪɪŋ tʃɪlʒɹən klʌŋ tə skɝts ɛvɹiwɛɹ. hi plʌnʒd θɹu ðɛm, dɑdʒɪŋ wɛɹ i kʊd, mʌɾɝɪŋ əpɑlədʒiz tə ðoʊz i ʃoʊldɝɾ əsaɪd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɪɡnɔɹ ðɛɹ stɑɹɾəld stɛɹz.

A woman screamed at the sight of him, in a laborer's coarse shirt and jerkin with a sword in his hand. Even invited, men did not go armed in the women's apartments unless the keep was under attack. Women filled the corridor, serving women in the black-and-gold, ladies of the keep in silks and laces, women in embroidered shawls with long fringes, all talking loudly at the same time, all demanding to know what was happening. Crying children clung to skirts everywhere. He plunged through them, dodging where he could, muttering apologies to those he shouldered aside, trying to ignore their startled stares.

wʌn ə ðə wɪmən ɪn ə ʃɔl tɝn tə ɡoʊ bæk ɪndə hɝ ɹum, ən i sɔ ðə bæk ə hɝ ʃɔl, sɔ ðə ɡlimɪŋ waɪt tɪɹdʒɹɑp ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə hɝ bæk. sʌɾənli hi ɹɛkəɡnaɪz feɪsəz i hæd sin ɪn ði aʊɾɝ kɔɹtʃjɑɹd. ɛɛs sədaɪ, stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪm ɪn əlɑɹm, naʊ.

One of the women in a shawl turned to go back into her room, and he saw the back of her shawl, saw the gleaming white teardrop in the middle of her back. Suddenly he recognized faces he had seen in the outer courtyard. Aes Sedai, staring at him in alarm, now.

"hu ɑɹ ju? wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ hɪɹ?"

"Who are you? What are you doing here?"

"ɪz ðə kip ʌndɝ ətæk? ænsɝ mi, mæn!"

"Is the keep under attack? Answer me, man!"

"hiz noʊ soʊlʒɝ. hu ɪz hi? wʌts hæpənɪŋ?"

"He's no soldier. Who is he? What's happening?"

"ɪts ðə jʌŋ saʊθlæn lɔɹd!"

"It's the young southland lord!"

"sʌmwʌn stɑp hɪm!"

"Someone stop him!"

fɪɹ pʊʃt ɪz lɪps bæk, bɛɹɪŋ ɪz tiθ, bʌɾ i kɛp muvɪŋ, ən tʃɹaɪd tə muv fæstɝ.

Fear pushed his lips back, baring his teeth, but he kept moving, and tried to move faster.

ðən ə wʊmən keɪm aʊɾ ɪndə ðə hɔl, feɪs-tə-feɪs wɪð hɪm, ən i stɑpt ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɪmsɛlf. hi ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðət feɪs əbʌv ðə ɹɛst; hi θɔɾ i wəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɪɾ ɪf i lɪv fɝɛvɝ. ði æmɪɝlɪn sit. hɝ aɪz waɪɾənd ət ðə saɪɾ ə hɪm, ən ʃi stɑɹɾəd bæk. ənʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðə tɔl wʊmən i hæd sin wɪð ðə stæf, pʊt hɝsɛlf bɪtwin ɪm ən ði æmɪɝlɪn, ʃaʊɾɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ əɾ ɪm ðəɾ i kəd nɑt meɪk aʊɾ oʊvɝ ði ɪnkɹisɪŋ bæbəl.

Then a woman came out into the hall, face-to-face with him, and he stopped in spite of himself. He recognized that face above the rest; he thought he would remember it if he lived forever. The Amyrlin Seat. Her eyes widened at the sight of him, and she started back. Another Aes Sedai, the tall woman he had seen with the staff, put herself between him and the Amyrlin, shouting something at him that he could not make out over the increasing babble.

ʃi noʊz. laɪt hɛlp mi, ʃi noʊz. mɔɪɹeɪn toʊl hɝ. snɑɹlɪŋ, hi ɹæn ɑn. laɪt, dʒʌs lemi meɪk ʃʊɹ ɛɡwinz seɪf bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ. . . . hi hɝd ʃaʊɾɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɪm, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt lɪsən.

She knows. Light help me, she knows. Moiraine told her. Snarling, he ran on. Light, just let me make sure Egwene's safe before they. . . . He heard shouting behind him, but he did not listen.

ðəɹ wɑz ɪnʌf tɝmɔɪl ɝaʊn ɪm aʊɾ ɪn ðə kip. mɛn ɹʌnɪŋ fəɹ ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹdz wɪð sɔɹdz ɪn hænd, nɛvɝ lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm. oʊvɝ ðə klæmɝ ʌv əlɑɹm bɛlz, hi kəd meɪk aʊɾ ʌðɝ nɔɪzɪz, naʊ. ʃaʊts. skɹimz. mɛɾəl ɹɪŋɪŋ ɑn mɛɾəl. hi hæd dʒʌs taɪm tə ɹilaɪz ðeɪ wɝ ðə saʊnz ə bæɾəl - faɪɾɪŋ? ɪnsaɪd fæl dæɹə? - wən θɹi tʃɹɑləks keɪm dæʃɪŋ ɝaʊn ə kɔɹnɝ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm.

There was enough turmoil around him out in the keep. Men running for the courtyards with swords in hand, never looking at him. Over the clamor of alarm bells, he could make out other noises, now. Shouts. Screams. Metal ringing on metal. He had just time to realize they were the sounds of battle - Fighting? Inside Fal Dara? - when three Trollocs came dashing around a corner in front of him.

hɛɹi snaʊts dɪstɔɹɾəd ʌðɝwaɪz hjumən feɪsəz, ən wʌn ə ðɛm hæd ɹæmz hɔɹnz. ðeɪ bɛɹd tiθ, ɹeɪzɪŋ saɪð-laɪk sɔɹdz əz ðeɪ spɛd təwɔɹd hɪm.

Hairy snouts distorted otherwise human faces, and one of them had ram's horns. They bared teeth, raising scythe-like swords as they sped toward him.

ðə hɔlweɪ ðət hæd bɪn fʊl ə ɹʌnɪŋ mɛn ə moʊmən bɪfɔɹ wɑz ɛmpti naʊ ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə θɹi tʃɹɑləks ən hɪmsɛlf. kɑt baɪ sɝpɹaɪz, hi ənʃiðd ɪz sɔɹɾ ɔkwɝdli, tʃɹaɪd hʌmɪŋbɝd kɪsəz ðə hʌniɹoʊz. ʃeɪkən ət faɪndɪŋ tʃɹɑləks ɪn ðə hɑɹɾ ə fæl dæɹə kip, hi dɪd ðə fɔɹm soʊ bædli læn wʊɾə stɔkt ɔf ɪn dɪsɡʌst. ə bɛɹ-snaʊɾəd tʃɹɑlɑk ɪveɪɾɪd ɪɾ izəli, bʌmpɪŋ ði ʌðɝ tu ɔf stʃɹaɪd fəɹ dʒʌst ən ɪnstənt.

The hallway that had been full of running men a moment before was empty now except for the three Trollocs and himself. Caught by surprise, he unsheathed his sword awkwardly, tried Hummingbird Kisses the Honeyrose. Shaken at finding Trollocs in the heart of Fal Dara keep, he did the form so badly Lan would have stalked off in disgust. A bear-snouted Trolloc evaded it easily, bumping the other two off stride for just an instant.

sʌɾənli ðəɹ wɝ ə dʌzən ʃaɪnɝənz ɹʌʃɪŋ pæst ɪm ət ðə tʃɹɑləks, mɛn hæf dʒɹɛst ɪn faɪnɝi fəɹ ðə fist, bʌt sɔɹdz ət ðə ɹɛɾi. ðə bɛɹ-snaʊɾəd tʃɹɑlɑk snɑɹəld əz ɪt daɪd, ən ɪts kəmpænjənz ɹæn, pɝsud baɪ ʃaʊɾɪŋ mɛn weɪvɪŋ stil. ʃaʊts ən skɹimz fɪl ði ɛɹ fɹəm ɛvɹiwɛɹ.

Suddenly there were a dozen Shienarans rushing past him at the Trollocs, men half dressed in finery for the feast, but swords at the ready. The bear-snouted Trolloc snarled as it died, and its companions ran, pursued by shouting men waving steel. Shouts and screams filled the air from everywhere.

ɛɡwin!

Egwene!

ɹænd tɝn dipɝ ɪndə ðə kip, ɹʌnɪŋ daʊn hɔlz ɛmpti ʌv laɪf, ðoʊ naʊ ən əɡɛn ə dɛd tʃɹɑlɑk leɪ ɑn ðə flɔɹ. əɹ ə dɛd mæn.

Rand turned deeper into the keep, running down halls empty of life, though now and again a dead Trolloc lay on the floor. Or a dead man.

ðən i keɪm tə ə kɹɔsɪŋ ə kɔɹɪɾɝz, ən tə hɪz lɛft wɑz ðə teɪl ɛn ʌv ə faɪt. sɪks tɑp-nɑɾɪd mɛn leɪ bliɾɪŋ ən stɪl, ən ə sɛvənθ wɑz daɪɪŋ. ðə mɹdʒɹɑl ɡeɪv ɪts sɔɹɾ ən ɛkstʃɹə twɪst əz ɪt pʊl ðə bleɪd fɹi ʌv ðə mænz bɛli, ən ðə soʊlʒɝ skɹimd əz i dʒɹɑpt ɪz sɔɹɾ ən fɛl. ðə feɪd muvd wɪð vaɪpɝəs ɡɹeɪs, ðə sɝpən ɪluʒən haɪɾənd baɪ ði ɑɹmɝ ə blæk, oʊvɝlæpɪŋ pleɪts ðət kʌvɝɾ ɪts tʃɛst. ɪt tɝnd, ən ðət peɪl, aɪləs feɪs stʌɾid ɹænd. ɪt stɑɹɾəd təwɔɹd hɪm, smaɪlɪŋ ə blʌdləs smaɪl, nɑt hɝiɪŋ. ɪt hæd noʊ nid tə hɝi fəɹ wʌn mæn əloʊn.

Then he came to a crossing of corridors, and to his left was the tail end of a fight. Six top-knotted men lay bleeding and still, and a seventh was dying. The Myrddraal gave its sword an extra twist as it pulled the blade free of the man's belly, and the soldier screamed as he dropped his sword and fell. The Fade moved with viperous grace, the serpent illusion heightened by the armor of black, overlapping plates that covered its chest. It turned, and that pale, eyeless face studied Rand. It started toward him, smiling a bloodless smile, not hurrying. It had no need to hurry for one man alone.

hi fɛlt ɹuɾəd wɛɹ i stʊd; hɪz tʌŋ stʌk tə ðə ɹuf ə hɪz maʊð. ðə lʊk ə ði aɪləs ɪz fɪɹ. ðət wɑz wʌt ðeɪ sɛɾ əlɔŋ ðə bɔɹɾɝ. hɪz hænz ʃʊk əz i ɹeɪzd ɪz sɔɹd. hi nɛvɝ ivən θɔɾ ʌv əsumɪŋ ðə vɔɪd. laɪt, ɪt dʒʌs kɪl sɛvən ɑɹm soʊlʒɝz təɡɛðɝ. laɪt, wʌɾ æm aɪ ɡoʊɪŋ tə du. laɪt!

He felt rooted where he stood; his tongue stuck to the roof of his mouth. The look of the Eyeless is fear. That was what they said along the Border. His hands shook as he raised his sword. He never even thought of assuming the void. Light, it just killed seven armed soldiers together. Light, what am I going to do. Light!

əbɹʌpli ðə mɹdʒɹɑl stɑpt, ɪts smaɪl ɡɔn.

Abruptly the Myrddraal stopped, its smile gone.

"ðɪs wʌn ɪz maɪn, ɹænd." ɹænd ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ əz ɪŋtʃɹ stɛpt ʌp bɪsaɪd hɪm, dɑɹk ən stɑki ɪn ə jɛloʊ fistdeɪ koʊt, sɔɹd hɛld ɪn boʊθ hænz. ɪŋtʃɹz dɑɹk aɪz nɛvɝ lɛf ðə feɪdz feɪs; ɪf ðə ʃaɪnɝən fɛl ðə fɪɹ ə ðət ɡeɪz, hi ɡeɪv noʊ saɪn. "tʃɹaɪ jɝsɛlf ɑn ə tʃɹɑlɑk əɹ tu," hi sɛd sɔfli, "bɪfɔɹ jə feɪs wʌn ə ðiz."

"This one is mine, Rand." Rand gave a start as Ingtar stepped up beside him, dark and stocky in a yellow feastday coat, sword held in both hands. Ingtar's dark eyes never left the Fade's face; if the Shienaran felt the fear of that gaze, he gave no sign. "Try yourself on a Trolloc or two," he said softly, "before you face one of these."

"aɪ wɑz kʌmɪŋ daʊn tə si ɪf ɛɡwin ɪz seɪf. ʃi wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə ðə dʌnʒən tə vɪzət feɪn, ən - "

"I was coming down to see if Egwene is safe. She was going to the dungeon to visit Fain, and - "

"ðɛn ɡoʊ si tə hɝ."

"Then go see to her."

ɹænd swɑloʊd. "wil teɪk ɪt təɡɛðɝ, ɪŋtʃɹ."

Rand swallowed. "We'll take it together, Ingtar."

"ju ɑɹən ɹɛɾi fəɹ ðɪs. ɡoʊ si tə jəɹ ɡɝl. ɡoʊ! jə wɑn tʃɹɑləks tə faɪn əɹ ʌnpɹətɛktɪd?"

"You aren't ready for this. Go see to your girl. Go! You want Trollocs to find her unprotected?"

fəɹ ə moʊmən ɹænd hʌŋ ðɛɹ, ʌndɪsaɪɾɪd. ðə feɪd hæd ɹeɪzd ɪts sɔɹd, fəɹ ɪŋtʃɹ. ə saɪlən snɑɹl twɪstəɾ ɪŋtʃɹz maʊθ, bʌt ɹænd nu ɪt wɑz nɑt fɪɹ. ən ɛɡwin kəd bi əloʊn ɪn ðə dʌnʒən wɪð feɪn, əɹ wɝs. stɪl i fɛlt əʃeɪmd əz i ɹæn fəɹ ðə stɛɹz ðət lɛɾ ʌndɝɡɹaʊnd. hi nu ə feɪdz lʊk kəd meɪk ɛni mæn əfɹeɪd, bʌɾ ɪŋtʃɹ hæd kɑŋkɝd ðə dʒɹɛd. hɪz stʌmək stɪl fɛl nɑɾɪd.

For a moment Rand hung there, undecided. The Fade had raised its sword, for Ingtar. A silent snarl twisted Ingtar's mouth, but Rand knew it was not fear. And Egwene could be alone in the dungeon with Fain, or worse. Still he felt ashamed as he ran for the stairs that led underground. He knew a Fade's look could make any man afraid, but Ingtar had conquered the dread. His stomach still felt knotted.

ðə kɔɹɪɾɝz bɪniθ ðə kip wɝ saɪlənt, ən fibli lɪt baɪ flɪkɝɪŋ, fɑɹ-speɪs læmps ɑn ðə wɔlz. hi sloʊɾ əz i keɪm kloʊsɝ tə ðə dʌnʒənz, kɹipɪŋ əz saɪlənli əz i kəɾ ɑn ɪz toʊz. ðə ɡɹeɪɾ ə hɪz buts ɑn ðə bɛɹ stoʊn sim tə fɪl ɪz ɪɹz. ðə dɔɹ tə ðə dʌnʒənz stʊd kɹækt oʊpən ə hændbɹidθ. ɪt ʃʊɾə bɪn kloʊzd ən boʊltəd.

The corridors beneath the keep were silent, and feebly lit by flickering, far-spaced lamps on the walls. He slowed as he came closer to the dungeons, creeping as silently as he could on his toes. The grate of his boots on the bare stone seemed to fill his ears. The door to the dungeons stood cracked open a handbreadth. It should have been closed and bolted.

stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə dɔɹ, hi tʃɹaɪd tə swɑloʊ ən kəd nɑt. hi oʊpən ɪz maʊθ tə kɔl aʊt, ðən ʃʌɾ ɪɾ əɡɛn kwɪkli. ɪf ɛɡwin wɑz ɪn ðəɹ ən ɪn tʃɹʌbəl, ʃaʊɾɪŋ wəɾ oʊnli wɔɹn huɛvɝ wɑz ɛndeɪnʒɝɪŋ hɝ. əɹ wʌtɛvɝ. teɪkɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ, hi sɛt hɪmsɛlf.

Staring at the door, he tried to swallow and could not. He opened his mouth to call out, then shut it again quickly. If Egwene was in there and in trouble, shouting would only warn whoever was endangering her. Or whatever. Taking a deep breath, he set himself.

ɪn wʌn moʊʃən i pʊʃt ðə dɔɹ waɪɾ oʊpən wɪð ðə skæbɝɾ ɪn ɪz lɛf hæn ən θɹu hɪmsɛlf ɪndə ðə dʌnʒən, tʌkɪŋ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ʌndɝ tə ɹoʊl θɹu ðə stʃɹɔ kʌvɝɪŋ ðə flɔɹ ən kʌm tə hɪz fit, spɪnɪŋ ðɪs weɪ ən ðət tu kwɪkli tə ɡɛɾ ə klɪɹ pɪktʃɝ ə ðə ɹum, lʊkɪŋ dɛspɝətli fəɹ ɛniwʌn u maɪɾ ətæk hɪm, lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ɛɡwin. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ wʌn ðɛɹ.

In one motion he pushed the door wide open with the scabbard in his left hand and threw himself into the dungeon, tucking his shoulder under to roll through the straw covering the floor and come to his feet, spinning this way and that too quickly to get a clear picture of the room, looking desperately for anyone who might attack him, looking for Egwene. There was no one there.

hɪz aɪz fɛl ɑn ðə teɪbəl, ən i stɑp dɛd, bɹɛθ ən ivən θɔt fɹizɪŋ. ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə stɪl-bɝnɪŋ læmp, əz ɪf tə meɪk ə sɛntɝpis, sæt ðə hɛdz ə ðə ɡɑɹdz ɪn tu pulz ə blʌd. ðɛɹ aɪz stɛɹɾ ət hɪm, waɪd wɪð fɪɹ, ən ðɛɹ maʊðz ɡeɪpt ɪn ə læst skɹim noʊ wʌn kəd hɪɹ. ɹænd ɡæɡd ən dʌbəld oʊvɝ; hɪz stʌmək hivd əɡɛn ən əɡɛn əz i vɑməɾəd ɪndə ðə stʃɹɔ. faɪnəli hi mænədʒ tə pʊl hɪmsɛlf ɪɹɛkt, skɹʌbɪŋ ɪz maʊθ wɪð ɪz sliv; hɪz θɹoʊt fɛl skɹeɪpt ɹɔ.

His eyes fell on the table, and he stopped dead, breath and even thought freezing. On either side of the still-burning lamp, as if to make a centerpiece, sat the heads of the guards in two pools of blood. Their eyes stared at him, wide with fear, and their mouths gaped in a last scream no one could hear. Rand gagged and doubled over; his stomach heaved again and again as he vomited into the straw. Finally he managed to pull himself erect, scrubbing his mouth with his sleeve; his throat felt scraped raw.

sloʊli hi bɪkeɪm əwɛɹ ə ðə ɹɛst ə ðə ɹum, oʊnli hæf sin ən nɑt teɪkən ɪn dʊɹɪŋ ɪz heɪsti sɝtʃ fəɹ ən ətækɝ. blʌɾi lʌmps ə flɛʃ leɪ skæɾɝd θɹu ðə stʃɹɔ. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ i kəd ɹɛkəɡnaɪz əz hjumən ɪksɛp ðə tu hɛdz. səm ə ðə pisəz lʊk tʃud. soʊ ðæts wʌt hæpən tə ðə ɹɛst ə ðɛɹ bɑɾiz. hi wɑz sɝpɹaɪzd ət ðə kɑmnəs ə hɪz θɔts, ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf i hæɾ ətʃiv ðə vɔɪd wɪθaʊt tʃɹaɪɪŋ. ɪt wɑz ðə ʃɑk, hi nu veɪɡli.

Slowly he became aware of the rest of the room, only half seen and not taken in during his hasty search for an attacker. Bloody lumps of flesh lay scattered through the straw. There was nothing he could recognize as human except the two heads. Some of the pieces looked chewed. So that's what happened to the rest of their bodies. He was surprised at the calmness of his thoughts, almost as if he had achieved the void without trying. It was the shock, he knew vaguely.

hi dɪd nɑt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz iðɝ ə ðə hɛdz; ðə ɡɑɹdz hæd bɪn tʃeɪnʒd sɪns i wɑz ðəɹ ɝliɝ. hi wɑz ɡlæd fəɹ ðæt. noʊɪŋ u ðeɪ wɝ, ivən tʃæŋɡʌ, wʊɾə meɪɾ ɪt wɝs. blʌd kʌvɝd ðə wɔlz, tu, bʌɾ ɪn skɹɔld lɛɾɝz, sɪŋɡəl wɝdz ən hoʊl sɛntənsəz splæʃt ɑn ɛvɹi wɪtʃ weɪ. səm wɝ hɑɹʃ ən æŋɡjəlɝ, ɪn ə læŋɡwədʒ i dɪd nɑt noʊ, ðoʊ hi ɹɛkəɡnaɪz tʃɹɑlɑk skɹɪpt. ʌðɝz i kəd ɹid, ən wɪʃt i kəd nɑt. blæsfəmiz ən ɑbsɛnɪɾiz bæɾ ɪnʌf tə meɪk ə steɪbəlɪhæn əɹ ə mɝtʃəns ɡɑɹd ɡoʊ peɪl.

He did not recognize either of the heads; the guards had been changed since he was there earlier. He was glad for that. Knowing who they were, even Changu, would have made it worse. Blood covered the walls, too, but in scrawled letters, single words and whole sentences splashed on every which way. Some were harsh and angular, in a language he did not know, though he recognized Trolloc script. Others he could read, and wished he could not. Blasphemies and obscenities bad enough to make a stablehand or a merchant's guard go pale.

"ɛɡwin." kɑmnəs vænɪʃt. ʃʌvɪŋ ɪz skæbɝd θɹu hɪz bɛlt, hi snætʃt ðə læmp fɹəm ðə teɪbəl, hɑɹdli noʊɾɪsɪŋ wən ðə hɛdz tɑpəld oʊvɝ. "ɛɡwin! wɛɹ ɑɹ ju?"

"Egwene." Calmness vanished. Shoving his scabbard through his belt, he snatched the lamp from the table, hardly noticing when the heads toppled over. "Egwene! Where are you?"

hi stɑɹɾəd təwɔɹd ði ɪnɝ dɔɹ, tʊk tu stɛps, ən stɑpt, stɛɹɪŋ. ðə wɝdz ɑn ðə dɔɹ, dɑɹk ən ɡlɪsnɪŋ wɛtli ɪn ðə laɪɾ ə hɪz læmp, wɝ pleɪn ɪnʌf.

He started toward the inner door, took two steps, and stopped, staring. The words on the door, dark and glistening wetly in the light of his lamp, were plain enough.

wɪl miɾ əɡɛn ɑn toʊmən hɛd.

WE WILL MEET AGAIN ON TOMAN HEAD.

ɪts nɛvɝ oʊvɝ, ælθɹ.

IT IS NEVER OVER, AL'THOR.

hɪz sɔɹd dʒɹɑp fɹəm ə hæn sʌɾənli nʌm. nɛvɝ teɪkɪŋ ɪz aɪz ɔf ðə dɔɹ, hi bɛn tə pɪk ɪɾ ʌp. ɪnstɛɾ i ɡɹæbd ə hændfʊl ə stʃɹɔ ən bɪɡæn skɹʌbɪŋ fjʊɹiəsli ət ðə wɝdz ɑn ðə dɔɹ. pæntɪŋ, hi skɹʌbd əntɪl ɪt wɑz ɔl wʌn blʌɾi smɪɹ, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt stɑp.

His sword dropped from a hand suddenly numb. Never taking his eyes off the door, he bent to pick it up. Instead he grabbed a handful of straw and began scrubbing furiously at the words on the door. Panting, he scrubbed until it was all one bloody smear, but he could not stop.

"wʌt dʒju du?"

"What do you do?"

ət ðə ʃɑɹp vɔɪs bɪhaɪn hɪm, hi wɝld, stupɪŋ tə siz ɪz sɔɹd.

At the sharp voice behind him, he whirled, stooping to seize his sword.

ə wʊmən stʊɾ ɪn ði aʊɾɝ dɔɹweɪ, bæk stɪf wɪð aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ. hɝ hɛɹ wɑz laɪk peɪl ɡoʊld, ɪn ə dʌzən əɹ mɔɹ bɹeɪdz, bʌɾ əɹ aɪz wɝ dɑɹk, ən ʃɑɹp ɑn ɪz feɪs. ʃi lʊk nɑt mʌtʃ oʊldɝ ðən hi, ən pɹɪɾi ɪn ə sʌlki weɪ, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ə taɪtnəs tə hɝ maʊθ i dɪd nɑt laɪk. ðən i sɔ ðə ʃɔl ʃi hæd ɹæp taɪtli ɝaʊn hɝ, wɪð ɪts lɔŋ, ɹɛd fɹɪnʒ.

A woman stood in the outer doorway, back stiff with outrage. Her hair was like pale gold, in a dozen or more braids, but her eyes were dark, and sharp on his face. She looked not much older than he, and pretty in a sulky way, but there was a tightness to her mouth he did not like. Then he saw the shawl she had wrapped tightly around her, with its long, red fringe.

ɛɛs sədaɪ. ən laɪt hɛlp mi, ʃiz ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ. "aɪ. . . . aɪ wɑz dʒʌst. . . . ɪts fɪlθi stʌf. vaɪl."

Aes Sedai. And Light help me, she's Red Ajah. "I. . . . I was just. . . . It's filthy stuff. Vile."

"ɛvɹiθɪŋ mʌs bi lɛft ɪɡzækli əz ɪts fəɹ əs tə ɪɡzæmɪn. tʌtʃ nʌθɪŋ." ʃi tʊk ə stɛp fɔɹwɝd, piɹɪŋ ət hɪm, ən i tʊk wʌn bæk. "jɛs. jɛs, əz aɪ θɔt. wʌn ə ðoʊz wɪð mɔɪɹeɪn. wʌt juv tə də wɪð ðɪs?" hɝ dʒɛstʃɝ tʊk ɪn ðə hɛdz ɑn ðə teɪbəl ən ðə blʌɾi skɹɔl ɑn ðə wɔlz.

"Everything must be left exactly as it is for us to examine. Touch nothing." She took a step forward, peering at him, and he took one back. "Yes. Yes, as I thought. One of those with Moiraine. What do you have to do with this?" Her gesture took in the heads on the table and the bloody scrawl on the walls.

fəɹ ə mɪnəɾ i ɡɑɡəld ət hɝ. "mi? nʌθɪŋ! aɪ keɪm daʊn hɪɹ tə faɪnd. . . . ɛɡwin!"

For a minute he goggled at her. "Me? Nothing! I came down here to find. . . . Egwene!"

hi tɝn tə oʊpən ði ɪnɝ dɔɹ, ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ʃaʊɾəd, "noʊ! jəl ænsɝ mi!"

He turned to open the inner door, and the Aes Sedai shouted, "No! You will answer me!"

sʌɾənli ɪt wɑz ɔl i kəd də tə stæn ʌp, tə kip hoʊldɪŋ ðə læmp ən ɪz sɔɹd. aɪsi koʊl skwizd əɾ ɪm fɹəm ɔl saɪdz. hɪz hɛd fɛl kɑɾ ɪn ə fɹoʊzən vaɪs; hi kəd bɛɹli bɹið fəɹ ðə pɹɛʃɝ ɑn ɪz tʃɛst.

Suddenly it was all he could do to stand up, to keep holding the lamp and his sword. Icy cold squeezed at him from all sides. His head felt caught in a frozen vise; he could barely breathe for the pressure on his chest.

"ænsɝ mi, bɔɪ. tɛl mi jəɹ neɪm."

"Answer me, boy. Tell me your name."

ɪnvoʊlʌntɝɪli hi ɡɹʌntɪd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ænsɝ əɡɛns ðə tʃɪl ðət sim tə bi pɹɛsɪŋ ɪz feɪs bæk ɪndə hɪz skʌl, kənstʃɹɪktɪŋ ɪz tʃɛs laɪk fɹoʊzən aɪɝn bænz. hi klɛntʃt ɪz dʒɔz tə kip ðə saʊn ɪn. peɪnfəli hi ɹoʊld ɪz aɪz tə ɡlɛɹ əɾ əɹ θɹu ə blɝ ə tɛɹz. ðə laɪt bɝn ju, ɛɛs sədaɪ! aɪ woʊn seɪ ə wɝd, ðə ʃædoʊ teɪk ju!

Involuntarily he grunted, trying to answer against the chill that seemed to be pressing his face back into his skull, constricting his chest like frozen iron bands. He clenched his jaws to keep the sound in. Painfully he rolled his eyes to glare at her through a blur of tears. The Light burn you, Aes Sedai! I won't say a word, the Shadow take you!

"ænsɝ mi, bɔɪ! naʊ!"

"Answer me, boy! Now!"

fɹoʊzən niɾəlz pɪɹst ɪz bɹeɪn wɪð æɡəni, ɡɹeɪɾɪd ɪndə hɪz boʊnz. ðə vɔɪd fɔɹmd ɪnsaɪɾ ɪm bɪfɔɹ i ivən ɹilaɪzd i hæd θɔɾ ʌv ɪt, bʌɾ ɪt kəd nɑt hoʊld aʊt ðə peɪn. dɪmli hi sɛns laɪɾ ən wɔɹmθ sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ðə dɪstəns. ɪt flɪkɝd kwizəli, bʌt ðə laɪt wɑz wɔɹm, ən i wɑz koʊld. dɪstən bɪɑnd noʊɪŋ, bʌt sʌmhaʊ dʒʌst wɪðɪn ɹitʃ. laɪt, soʊ koʊld. aɪ hæv tə ɹitʃ . . . wʌt? ʃiz kɪlɪŋ mi. aɪ hæv tə ɹitʃ ɪt, əɹ ʃɪl kɪl mi. dɛspɝətli hi stʃɹɛtʃt təwɔɹd ðə laɪt.

Frozen needles pierced his brain with agony, grated into his bones. The void formed inside him before he even realized he had thought of it, but it could not hold out the pain. Dimly he sensed light and warmth somewhere in the distance. It flickered queasily, but the light was warm, and he was cold. Distant beyond knowing, but somehow just within reach. Light, so cold. I have to reach . . . what? She's killing me. I have to reach it, or she'll kill me. Desperately he stretched toward the light.

"wʌɾ ɪz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn hɪɹ?"

"What is going on here?"

əbɹʌpli ðə koʊld ən ðə pɹɛʃɝ ən ðə niɾəlz vænɪʃt. hɪz niz sæɡd, bʌɾ i fɔɹst əm stɪf. hi wəd nɑt fɔl tə hɪz niz; hi wəd nɑt ɡɪv əɹ ðə sæɾəsfækʃən. ðə vɔɪd wɑz ɡɔn, tu, əz sʌɾənli əz ɪt hæd kʌm. ʃi wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kɪl mi. pæntɪŋ, hi ɹeɪzd ɪz hɛd. mɔɪɹeɪn stʊɾ ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ.

Abruptly the cold and the pressure and the needles vanished. His knees sagged, but he forced them stiff. He would not fall to his knees; he would not give her the satisfaction. The void was gone, too, as suddenly as it had come. She was trying to kill me. Panting, he raised his head. Moiraine stood in the doorway.

"aɪ æskt wʌɾ ɪz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn hɪɹ, liɑnʒɹɪn," ʃi sɛd.

"I asked what is going on here, Liandrin," she said.

"aɪ faʊn ðɪs bɔɪ hɪɹ," ðə ɹɛɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹɪplaɪd kɑmli. "ðə ɡɑɹdz ɑɹ mɝɾɝd, ən hɪɹ i ɪz. wʌn ə jʊɹz. ən wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ hɪɹ, mɔɪɹeɪn? ðə bæɾəl ɪz əbʌv, nɑt hɪɹ."

"I found this boy here," the Red Aes Sedai replied calmly. "The guards are murdered, and here he is. One of yours. And what are you doing here, Moiraine? The battle is above, not here."

"aɪ kəɾ æsk ðə seɪm ə ju, liɑnʒɹɪn." mɔɪɹeɪn lʊkt ɝaʊn ðə ɹum wɪð oʊnli ə slaɪt taɪɾənɪŋ ə hɝ maʊθ fəɹ ðə tʃɑɹnəl. "waɪ ɑɹ jə hɪɹ?"

"I could ask the same of you, Liandrin." Moiraine looked around the room with only a slight tightening of her mouth for the charnel. "Why are you here?"

ɹænd tɝn əweɪ fɹəm ðɛm, ɔkwɝdli ʃʌv bæk ðə boʊls ɑn ði ɪnɝ dɔɹ ən pʊld ɪɾ oʊpən. "ɛɡwin keɪm daʊn hɪɹ," hi ənaʊns fəɹ ɛniwʌn u kɛɹd, ən wɛn ɪn, hoʊldɪŋ ɪz læmp haɪ. hɪz niz kɛpt wɑntɪŋ tə ɡɪv weɪ; hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ haʊ hi steɪɾ ɑn ɪz fit, oʊnli ðəɾ i hæd tə faɪn ɛɡwin. "ɛɡwin!"

Rand turned away from them, awkwardly shoved back the bolts on the inner door and pulled it open. "Egwene came down here," he announced for anyone who cared, and went in, holding his lamp high. His knees kept wanting to give way; he was not sure how he stayed on his feet, only that he had to find Egwene. "Egwene!"

ə hɑloʊ ɡɝɡəl ən ə θɹæʃɪŋ saʊn keɪm fɹəm ɪz ɹaɪt, ən i θɹʌs ðə læmp ðət weɪ. ðə pɹɪznɝ ɪn ðə fænsi koʊt wɑz sæɡɪŋ əɡɛns ði aɪɝn ɡɹɪl ə hɪz sɛl, hɪz bɛlt lupt ɝaʊn ðə bɑɹz ən ðən ɝaʊn ɪz nɛk. əz ɹænd lʊkt, hi ɡeɪv wʌn læs kɪk, skɹeɪpɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə stʃɹɔ-kʌvɝd flɔɹ, ən wɑz stɪl, tʌŋ ən aɪz bʌlʒɪŋ aʊɾ ʌv ə feɪs ɡɔn ɔlmoʊs blæk. hɪz niz ɔlmoʊs tʌtʃt ðə flɔɹ; hi cʊɾə stʊɾ ɛnitaɪm i wɑntəd tə.

A hollow gurgle and a thrashing sound came from his right, and he thrust the lamp that way. The prisoner in the fancy coat was sagging against the iron grille of his cell, his belt looped around the bars and then around his neck. As Rand looked, he gave one last kick, scraping across the straw-covered floor, and was still, tongue and eyes bulging out of a face gone almost black. His knees almost touched the floor; he could have stood anytime he wanted to.

ʃɪvɝɪŋ, ɹænd pɪɹɾ ɪndə ðə nɛkst sɛl. ðə bɪɡ mæn wɪð ðə sʌŋkən nʌkəlz hʌɾəld ɪn ðə bæk ə hɪz sɛl, aɪz əz waɪɾ əz ðeɪ kəɾ oʊpən. ət ðə saɪɾ ə ɹænd, hi skɹimd ən twɪstəɾ ɝaʊnd, klɔɪŋ fɹæntəkəli ət ðə stoʊn wɔl.

Shivering, Rand peered into the next cell. The big man with the sunken knuckles huddled in the back of his cell, eyes as wide as they could open. At the sight of Rand, he screamed and twisted around, clawing frantically at the stone wall.

"aɪ woʊn hɝt ju," ɹænd kɔld. ðə mæn kɛpt ɑn skɹimɪŋ ən dɪɡɪŋ. hɪz hænz wɝ blʌɾi, ən ɪz skɹæbəlɪŋz stʃɹikt əkɹɔs dɑɹk, kɑndʒil smɪɹz. ðɪs wɑz nɑɾ ɪz fɝst ətɛmp tə dɪɡ θɹu ðə stoʊn wɪð ɪz bɛɹ hænz.

"I won't hurt you," Rand called. The man kept on screaming and digging. His hands were bloody, and his scrabblings streaked across dark, conjealed smears. This was not his first attempt to dig through the stone with his bare hands.

ɹænd tɝn əweɪ, ɹɪliv ðəɾ ɪz stʌmək wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ɛmpti. bʌt ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ i kəd də fəɹ iðɝ ə ðɛm. "ɛɡwin!"

Rand turned away, relieved that his stomach was already empty. But there was nothing he could do for either of them. "Egwene!"

hɪz laɪt faɪnəli ɹitʃt ði ɛn ə ðə sɛlz. ðə dɔɹ tə feɪnz sɛl stʊɾ oʊpən, ən ðə sɛl wɑz ɛmpti, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðə tu ʃeɪps ɑn ðə stoʊn ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə sɛl ðət meɪd ɹænd lip fɔɹwɝɾ ən dʒɹɑp tə hɪz niz bɪtwin ðɛm.

His light finally reached the end of the cells. The door to Fain's cell stood open, and the cell was empty, but it was the two shapes on the stone in front of the cell that made Rand leap forward and drop to his knees between them.

ɛɡwin ən mæt leɪ spɹɔl boʊnləsli, ʌnkɑnʃəs . . . əɹ dɛd. wɪð ə flʌɾ ə ɹɪlif i sɔ ðɛɹ tʃɛsts ɹaɪz ən fɔl. ðəɹ dɪd nɑt sim tə bi ə mɑɹk ɑn iðɝ ə ðɛm.

Egwene and Mat lay sprawled bonelessly, unconscious . . . or dead. With a flood of relief he saw their chests rise and fall. There did not seem to be a mark on either of them.

"ɛɡwin? mæt?" sɛɾɪŋ ðə sɔɹd daʊn, hi ʃʊk ɛɡwin dʒɛnli. "ɛɡwin?" ʃi dɪd nɑɾ oʊpən əɹ aɪz. "mɔɪɹeɪn! ɛɡwinz hɝt! ən mæt!" mæts bɹiðɪŋ saʊndəd leɪbɝd, ən ɪz feɪs wɑz dɛθli peɪl. ɹænd fɛlt ɔlmoʊs laɪk kɹaɪɪŋ. ɪt wɑz səpoʊz tə hɝt mi. aɪ neɪm ðə dɑɹk wʌn. meɪn!

"Egwene? Mat?" Setting the sword down, he shook Egwene gently. "Egwene?" She did not open her eyes. "Moiraine! Egwene's hurt! And Mat!" Mat's breathing sounded labored, and his face was deathly pale. Rand felt almost like crying. It was supposed to hurt me. I named the Dark One. Me!

"du nɑt muv ðɛm." mɔɪɹeɪn dɪd nɑt saʊn əpsɛt, əɹ ivən sɝpɹaɪzd.

"Do not move them." Moiraine did not sound upset, or even surprised.

ðə tʃeɪmbɝ wɑz sʌɾənli flʌɾəd wɪð laɪɾ əz ðə tu ɛɛs sədaɪ ɛntɝd. itʃ bælənst ə ɡloʊɪŋ bɔl ə kul laɪt, floʊɾɪŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ əbʌv əɹ hænd.

The chamber was suddenly flooded with light as the two Aes Sedai entered. Each balanced a glowing ball of cool light, floating in the air above her hand.

liɑnʒɹɪn mɑɹtʃt stʃɹeɪt daʊn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə waɪd hɔl, hoʊldɪŋ əɹ skɝts ʌp aʊɾ ə ðə stʃɹɔ wɪð əɹ fɹi hænd, bʌt mɔɪɹeɪn pɔz tə lʊk ət ðə tu pɹɪznɝz bɪfɔɹ fɑloʊɪŋ. "ðɛɹ ɪz nʌθɪŋ tə də fəɹ ðə wʌn," ʃi sɛd, "æn ði ʌðɝ kən weɪt."

Liandrin marched straight down the middle of the wide hall, holding her skirts up out of the straw with her free hand, but Moiraine paused to look at the two prisoners before following. "There is nothing to do for the one," she said, "and the other can wait."

liɑnʒɹɪn ɹitʃt ɹænd fɝst ən bɪɡæn tə bɛn təwɔɹɾ ɛɡwin, bʌt mɔɪɹeɪn dɑɹɾɪd ɪn əhɛɾ ə hɝ ən leɪɾ əɹ fɹi hæn ɑn ɛɡwinz hɛd. liɑnʒɹɪn stʃɹeɪɾənd wɪð ə ɡɹɪmɑs.

Liandrin reached Rand first and began to bend toward Egwene, but Moiraine darted in ahead of her and laid her free hand on Egwene's head. Liandrin straightened with a grimace.

"ʃi ɪz nɑt bædli hɝt," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛɾ æftɝ ə moʊmənt. "ʃi wɑz stʃɹʌk hɪɹ." ʃi tʃɹeɪst ən ɛɹiə ɑn ðə saɪɾ ʌv ɛɡwinz hɛd, kʌvɝd baɪ hɝ hɛɹ; ɹænd kəd si nʌθɪŋ dɪfɹən əbaʊɾ ɪt. "ðæɾ ɪz ði oʊnli ɪnʒɝi ʃiz teɪkən. ʃɪl bi ɔl ɹaɪt."

"She is not badly hurt," Moiraine said after a moment. "She was struck here." She traced an area on the side of Egwene's head, covered by her hair; Rand could see nothing different about it. "That is the only injury she has taken. She will be all right."

ɹænd lʊk fɹəm wʌn ɛɛs sədaɪ tə ði ʌðɝ. "wʌɾ əbaʊt mæt?" liɑnʒɹɪn ɑɹtʃt ən aɪbɹaʊ əɾ ɪm ən tɝn tə wɑtʃ mɔɪɹeɪn wɪð ə ɹaɪ ɪkspɹɛʃən.

Rand looked from one Aes Sedai to the other. "What about Mat?" Liandrin arched an eyebrow at him and turned to watch Moiraine with a wry expression.

"bi kwaɪət," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. fɪŋɡɝz stɪl laɪɪŋ ɑn ði ɛɹiə wɛɹ ʃi sɛɾ ɛɡwin hæd bɪn hɪt, ʃi kloʊzd əɹ aɪz. ɛɡwin mɝmɝɾ ən stɝd, ðən leɪ stɪl.

"Be quiet," Moiraine said. Fingers still lying on the area where she said Egwene had been hit, she closed her eyes. Egwene murmured and stirred, then lay still.

"ɪz ʃi . . . ?"

"Is she . . . ?"

"ʃi ɪz slipɪŋ, ɹænd. ʃɪl bi wɛl, bʌt ʃi mʌst slip." mɔɪɹeɪn ʃɪftəd tə mæt, bʌt hɪɹ ʃi oʊnli tʌtʃt ɪm fəɹ ə moʊmən bɪfɔɹ dʒɹɔɪŋ bæk. "ðɪs ɪz mɔɹ sɪɹiəs," ʃi sɛd sɔfli. ʃi fʌmbəld ət mæts weɪst, pʊlɪŋ ɪz koʊɾ oʊpən, ən meɪɾ ən æŋɡɹi saʊnd. "ðə dæɡɝ ɪz ɡɔn."

"She is sleeping, Rand. She will be well, but she must sleep." Moiraine shifted to Mat, but here she only touched him for a moment before drawing back. "This is more serious," she said softly. She fumbled at Mat's waist, pulling his coat open, and made an angry sound. "The dagger is gone."

"wʌt dæɡɝ?" liɑnʒɹɪn æskt.

"What dagger?" Liandrin asked.

vɔɪsəz sʌɾənli keɪm fɹəm ði aʊɾɝ ɹum, mɛn ɪkskleɪmɪŋ ɪn dɪsɡʌst ən æŋɡɝ.

Voices suddenly came from the outer room, men exclaiming in disgust and anger.

"ɪn hɪɹ," mɔɪɹeɪn kɔld. "bɹɪŋ tu lɪɾɝz. kwɪkli." sʌmwʌn ɪn ði aʊɾɝ ɹum ɹeɪzd ə kɹaɪ fəɹ lɪɾɝz.

"In here," Moiraine called. "Bring two litters. Quickly." Someone in the outer room raised a cry for litters.

"feɪn ɪz ɡɔn," ɹænd sɛd.

"Fain is gone," Rand said.

ðə tu ɛɛs sədaɪ lʊkt ət hɪm. hi kəd ɹid nʌθɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ feɪsəz. ðɛɹ aɪz ɡlɪɾɝd ɪn ðə laɪt.

The two Aes Sedai looked at him. He could read nothing on their faces. Their eyes glittered in the light.

"soʊ aɪ si," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛɾ ɪn ə flæt vɔɪs.

"So I see," Moiraine said in a flat voice.

"aɪ toʊld əɹ nɑt tə kʌm. aɪ toʊld əɹ i wɑz deɪnʒɝəs."

"I told her not to come. I told her he was dangerous."

"wɛn aɪ keɪm," liɑnʒɹɪn sɛɾ ɪn ə koʊl vɔɪs, "hi wɑz dɪstʃɹɔɪɪŋ ðə ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪn ði aʊɾɝ tʃeɪmbɝ."

"When I came," Liandrin said in a cold voice, "he was destroying the writing in the outer chamber."

hi ʃɪftəɾ ənizəli ɑn ɪz niz. ði ɛɛs sədaɪz aɪz simd əlaɪk, naʊ. mɛʒɝɪŋ ən weɪɪŋ hɪm, kul ən tɛɹəbəl.

He shifted uneasily on his knees. The Aes Sedai's eyes seemed alike, now. Measuring and weighing him, cool and terrible.

"ɪt - ɪt wɑz fɪlθ," hi sɛd. "dʒʌs fɪlθ." ðeɪ stɪl lʊkt ət hɪm, nɑt spikɪŋ. "ju doʊn θɪŋk aɪ. . . . mɔɪɹeɪn, jə kæn θɪŋk aɪ hæɾ ɛniθɪŋ tə də wɪð - wɪð wʌt hæpən aʊt ðɛɹ." laɪt, dɪɾ aɪ? aɪ neɪm ðə dɑɹk wʌn.

"It - it was filth," he said. "Just filth." They still looked at him, not speaking. "You don't think I. . . . Moiraine, you can't think I had anything to do with - with what happened out there." Light, did I? I named the Dark One.

ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ænsɝ, ən i fɛlt ə tʃɪl ðət wɑz nɑt lɛsən baɪ mɛn ɹʌʃɪŋ ɪn wɪð tɔɹtʃɪz ən læmps. mɔɪɹeɪn ən liɑnʒɹɪn lɛt ðɛɹ ɡloʊɪŋ bɔlz wɪŋk aʊt. ðə læmps ən tɔɹtʃɪz dɪd nɑt ɡɪv əz mʌtʃ laɪt; ʃædoʊz spɹæŋ ʌp ɪn ðə dɛpθs ə ðə sɛlz. mɛn wɪð lɪɾɝz hɝid tə ðə fɪɡjɝz laɪɪŋ ɑn ðə flɔɹ. ɪŋtʃɹ lɛd ðɛm. hɪz tɑpnɑɾ ɔlmoʊs kwɪvɝd wɪð æŋɡɝ, ən i lʊkt iɡɝ tə faɪn sʌmθɪŋ ɑn wɪtʃ tə juz ɪz sɔɹd.

She did not answer, and he felt a chill that was not lessened by men rushing in with torches and lamps. Moiraine and Liandrin let their glowing balls wink out. The lamps and torches did not give as much light; shadows sprang up in the depths of the cells. Men with litters hurried to the figures lying on the floor. Ingtar led them. His topknot almost quivered with anger, and he looked eager to find something on which to use his sword.

"soʊ ðə dɑɹkfɹɛn ɪz ɡɔn, tu," hi ɡɹaʊld. "wɛl, ɪts ðə list ʌv wʌɾ əz hæpən ðɪs naɪt."

"So the Darkfriend is gone, too," he growled. "Well, it's the least of what has happened this night."

"ðə list ivən hɪɹ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd ʃɑɹpli. ʃi dɝɛktəd ðə mɛn pʊɾɪŋ ɛɡwin ən mæt ɑn ðə lɪɾɝz. "ðə ɡɝl ɪz tə bi teɪkən tə hɝ ɹum. ʃi nidz ə wʊmən tə wɑtʃ ɪn keɪs ʃi weɪks ɪn ðə naɪt. ʃi meɪ bi fɹaɪɾənd, bʌt mɔɹ ðən ɛniθɪŋ ɛls ʃi nidz slip, naʊ. ðə bɔɪ. . . ." ʃi tʌtʃt mæt əz tu mɛn lɪftəɾ ɪz lɪɾɝ, ən pʊld əɹ hæn bæk kwɪkli. "teɪk ɪm tə ði æmɪɝlɪn sits tʃeɪmbɝz. faɪn ði æmɪɝlɪn wɛɹɛvɝ ʃi ɪz, ən tɛl əɹ hiz ðɛɹ. tɛl əɹ ɪz neɪm ɪz meɪtʃɹim kɔθən. əl dʒɔɪn əɹ əz sun əz aɪm eɪbəl."

"The least even here," Moiraine said sharply. She directed the men putting Egwene and Mat on the litters. "The girl is to be taken to her room. She needs a woman to watch in case she wakes in the night. She may be frightened, but more than anything else she needs sleep, now. The boy. . . ." She touched Mat as two men lifted his litter, and pulled her hand back quickly. "Take him to the Amyrlin Seat's chambers. Find the Amyrlin wherever she is, and tell her he is there. Tell her his name is Matrim Cauthon. I will join her as soon as I am able."

"ði æmɪɝlɪn!" liɑnʒɹɪn ɪkskleɪmd. "ju θɪŋk tə hæv ði æmɪɝlɪn əz hilɝ fəɹ jəɹ - jəɹ pɛt? jə ɑɹ mæd, mɔɪɹeɪn."

"The Amyrlin!" Liandrin exclaimed. "You think to have the Amyrlin as Healer for your - your pet? You are mad, Moiraine."

"ði æmɪɝlɪn sit," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd kɑmli, "dʌz nɑt ʃɛɹ jəɹ ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ pɹɛdʒəɾɪsɪz, liɑnʒɹɪn. ʃɪl hil ə mæn wɪθaʊt niɾ ʌv ə spɛʃəl jus fəɹ hɪm. ɡoʊ əhɛd," ʃi toʊl ðə lɪɾɝ bɛɹɝz.

"The Amyrlin Seat," Moiraine said calmly, "does not share your Red Ajah prejudices, Liandrin. She will Heal a man without need of a special use for him. Go ahead," she told the litter bearers.

liɑnʒɹɪn wɑtʃt əm liv, mɔɪɹeɪn ən ðə mɛn kæɹiɪŋ mæt ən ɛɡwin, ðən tɝn tə stɛɹ ət ɹænd. hi tʃɹaɪd tə ɪɡnɔɹ hɝ. hi kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾəd ɑn skæbɑɹɾɪŋ ɪz sɔɹɾ ən bɹʌʃɪŋ ɔf ðə stʃɹɔ ðət klʌŋ tə hɪz ʃɝɾ ən bɹitʃɪz. wən i ɹeɪzd ɪz hɛd, ðoʊ, ʃi wɑz stɪl stʌɾiɪŋ hɪm, hɝ feɪs əz blæŋk əz aɪs. seɪɪŋ nʌθɪŋ, ʃi tɝn tə kənsɪɾɝ ði ʌðɝ mɛn θɔtfəli. wʌn hɛl ðə bɑɾi ʌv ðə hæŋ mæn ʌp waɪl ənʌðɝ wɝk tə ənfæstən ðə bɛlt. ɪŋtʃɹ ən ði ʌðɝz weɪɾəd ɹɪspɛkfəli. wɪð ə læst ɡlæns ət ɹænd, ʃi lɛft, hɛd hɛld laɪk ə kwin.

Liandrin watched them leave, Moiraine and the men carrying Mat and Egwene, then turned to stare at Rand. He tried to ignore her. He concentrated on scabbarding his sword and brushing off the straw that clung to his shirt and breeches. When he raised his head, though, she was still studying him, her face as blank as ice. Saying nothing, she turned to consider the other men thoughtfully. One held the body of the hanged man up while another worked to unfasten the belt. Ingtar and the others waited respectfully. With a last glance at Rand, she left, head held like a queen.

"ə hɑɹd wʊmən," ɪŋtʃɹ mʌɾɝd, ðən sim sɝpɹaɪz ðəɾ i hæd spoʊkən. "wʌt hæpən hɪɹ, ɹænd ælθɹ?"

"A hard woman," Ingtar muttered, then seemed surprised that he had spoken. "What happened here, Rand al'Thor?"

ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ, ɪksɛp ðət feɪn ɪskeɪp sʌmhaʊ. ən hɝɾ ɛɡwin ən mæt duɪŋ ɪt. aɪ sɔ ðə ɡɑɹdʒɹum" - hi ʃʌɾɝəd - "bʌɾ ɪn hɪɹ. . . . wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɑz, ɪŋtʃɹ, ɪt skɛɹd ðət fɛloʊ bæɾ ɪnʌf ðəɾ i hʌŋ hɪmsɛlf. aɪ θɪŋk ði ʌðɝ wʌnz ɡɔn mæd fɹəm siɪŋ ɪt."

Rand shook his head. "I don't know, except that Fain escaped somehow. And hurt Egwene and Mat doing it. I saw the guardroom" - he shuddered - "but in here. . . . Whatever it was, Ingtar, it scared that fellow bad enough that he hung himself. I think the other one's gone mad from seeing it."

"wi ɑɹ ɔl ɡoʊɪŋ mæd tənaɪt."

"We are all going mad tonight."

"ðə feɪd . . . jə kɪld ɪt?"

"The Fade . . . you killed it?"

"noʊ!" ɪŋtʃɹ slæmd ɪz sɔɹɾ ɪndə ɪts ʃiθ; ðə hɪl stʌk ʌp əbʌv ɪz ɹaɪt ʃoʊldɝ. hi simd æŋɡɹi ən əʃeɪmd ət ðə seɪm taɪm. "ɪts aʊɾ ə ðə kip baɪ naʊ, əlɔŋ wɪð ðə ɹɛst ʌv wʌt wi kəd nɑt kɪl."

"No!" Ingtar slammed his sword into its sheath; the hilt stuck up above his right shoulder. He seemed angry and ashamed at the same time. "It's out of the keep by now, along with the rest of what we could not kill."

"æt lis jəɹ əlaɪv, ɪŋtʃɹ. ðət feɪd kɪl sɛvən mɛn!"

"At least you're alive, Ingtar. That Fade killed seven men!"

"əlaɪv? ɪz ðət soʊ ɪmpɔɹɾənt?" sʌɾənli ɪŋtʃɹz feɪs wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ æŋɡɹi, bʌt taɪɝɾ ən fʊl ə peɪn. "wi hæɾ ɪɾ ɪn əɹ hænz. ɪn əɹ hænz! ən wi lɔst ɪt, ɹænd. lɔst ɪt!" hi saʊndəɾ əz ɪf i kəd nɑt bɪliv wʌɾ i wɑz seɪɪŋ.

"Alive? Is that so important?" Suddenly Ingtar's face was no longer angry, but tired and full of pain. "We had it in our hands. In our hands! And we lost it, Rand. Lost it!" He sounded as if he could not believe what he was saying.

"lɔst wʌt?" ɹænd æskt.

"Lost what?" Rand asked.

"ðə hɔɹn! ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ. ɪts ɡɔn, tʃɛst ən ɔl."

"The Horn! The Horn of Valere. It's gone, chest and all."

"bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɪn ðə stʃɹɔŋɡɹum."

"But it was in the strongroom."

"ðə stʃɹɔŋɡɹum wɑz luɾəd," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd wɛɹəli. "ðeɪ dɪd nɑt teɪk mʌtʃ, ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə hɔɹn. wʌt ðeɪ kəd stʌf ɪn ðɛɹ pɑkəts. aɪ wɪʃ ðeɪ hæd teɪkən ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls ən lɛf ðæt. ɹoʊnən ɪz dɛd, ən ðə wɑtʃmən i hæd ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə stʃɹɔŋɡɹum." hɪz vɔɪs bɪkeɪm kwaɪət. "wɛn aɪ wɑz ə bɔɪ, ɹoʊnən hɛl dʒəhɑn taʊɝ wɪð twɛnti mɛn əɡɛnst ə θaʊzən tʃɹɑləks. hi dɪd nɑt ɡoʊ daʊn izəli, ðoʊ. ði oʊl mæn hæd blʌɾ ɑn ɪz dæɡɝ. noʊ mæn kən æsk mɔɹ ðən ðæt." hi wɑz saɪlən fəɹ ə moʊmənt. "ðeɪ keɪm ɪn θɹu ðə dɔɡ ɡeɪt, ən lɛf ðə seɪm weɪ. wi pʊɾ ən ɛn tə fɪfti əɹ mɔɹ, bʌt tu mɛni ɪskeɪpt. tʃɹɑləks! wiv nɛvɝ bɪfɔɹ hæd tʃɹɑləks ɪnsaɪd ðə kip. nɛvɝ!"

"The strongroom was looted," Ingtar said wearily. "They did not take much, except for the Horn. What they could stuff in their pockets. I wish they had taken everything else and left that. Ronan is dead, and the watchmen he had guarding the strongroom." His voice became quiet. "When I was a boy, Ronan held Jehaan Tower with twenty men against a thousand Trollocs. He did not go down easily, though. The old man had blood on his dagger. No man can ask more than that." He was silent for a moment. "They came in through the Dog Gate, and left the same way. We put an end to fifty or more, but too many escaped. Trollocs! We've never before had Trollocs inside the keep. Never!"

"haʊ kəd ðeɪ ɡɛɾ ɪn θɹu ðə dɔɡ ɡeɪt, ɪŋtʃɹ? wʌn mæn kəd stɑp ə hʌnʒɹəd ðɛɹ. ən ɔl ðə ɡeɪts wɝ bɑɹd." hi ʃɪftəɾ ənizəli, ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ waɪ. "ðə ɡɑɹdz wəd nɑɾ əv oʊpən ɪt tə lɛɾ ɛnibəɾi ɪn."

"How could they get in through the Dog Gate, Ingtar? One man could stop a hundred there. And all the gates were barred." He shifted uneasily, remembering why. "The guards would not have opened it to let anybody in."

"ðɛɹ θɹoʊts wɝ kʌt," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd. "boʊθ ɡʊd mɛn, ən jɛt ðeɪ wɝ bʊtʃɝd laɪk pɪɡz. ɪt wɑz dʌn fɹəm ɪnsaɪd. sʌmwʌn kɪl ðɛm, ðən oʊpən ðə ɡeɪt. sʌmwʌn u kəd ɡɛt kloʊs tə ðɛm wɪθaʊt səspɪʃən. sʌmwʌn ðeɪ nu."

"Their throats were cut," Ingtar said. "Both good men, and yet they were butchered like pigs. It was done from inside. Someone killed them, then opened the gate. Someone who could get close to them without suspicion. Someone they knew."

ɹænd lʊkt ət ði ɛmpti sɛl wɛɹ pdən feɪn hæd bɪn. "bʌt ðət minz. . . ."

Rand looked at the empty cell where Padan Fain had been. "But that means. . . ."

"jɛs. ðəɹ ɑɹ dɑɹkfɹɛnz ɪnsaɪd fæl dæɹə. əɹ wɝ. wɪl sun noʊ ɪf ðæts ðə keɪs. keɪdʒɪn ɪz tʃɛkɪŋ naʊ tə si ɪf ɛniwʌn ɪz mɪsɪŋ. pis! tʃɹɛtʃɝi ɪn fæl dæɹə kip!" skaʊlɪŋ, hi lʊkt ɝaʊn ðə dʌnʒən, ət ðə mɛn weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ hɪm. ðeɪ ɔl hæd sɔɹdz, wɔɹn oʊvɝ fistdeɪ kloʊðz, ən səm hæd hɛlməts. "wi ɑɹən duɪŋ ɛni ɡʊd hɪɹ. aʊt! ɛvɹiwʌn!" ɹænd dʒɔɪn ðə wɪðdʒɹɔəl. ɪŋtʃɹ tæpt ɹændz dʒɝkɪn. "wʌɾ ɪz ðɪs? hæv jə dɪsaɪɾɪd tə bɪkʌm ə steɪbəlmən?"

"Yes. There are Darkfriends inside Fal Dara. Or were. We will soon know if that's the case. Kajin is checking now to see if anyone is missing. Peace! Treachery in Fal Dara keep!" Scowling, he looked around the dungeon, at the men waiting for him. They all had swords, worn over feastday clothes, and some had helmets. "We aren't doing any good here. Out! Everyone!" Rand joined the withdrawal. Ingtar tapped Rand's jerkin. "What is this? Have you decided to become a stableman?"

"ɪts ə lɔŋ stɔɹi," ɹænd sɛd. "tu lɔŋ tə tɛl hɪɹ. meɪbi səm ʌðɝ taɪm." meɪbi nɛvɝ, ɪf aɪm lʌki. meɪbi aɪ kən ɪskeɪp ɪn ɔl ðɪs kənfjuʒən. noʊ, aɪ kænt. nɑɾ əntɪl aɪ noʊ ɛɡwinz ɔl ɹaɪt. ən mæt. laɪt, wʌt wɪl hæpən tə hɪm wɪθaʊt ðə dæɡɝ? "aɪ səpoʊz lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝz dʌbəl ðə ɡɑɹɾ ɑn ɔl ðə ɡeɪts."

"It's a long story," Rand said. "Too long to tell here. Maybe some other time." Maybe never, if I'm lucky. Maybe I can escape in all this confusion. No, I can't. Not until I know Egwene's all right. And Mat. Light, what will happen to him without the dagger? "I suppose Lord Agelmar's doubled the guard on all the gates."

"tʃɹɪpəld," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛɾ ɪn toʊnz ə sæɾəsfækʃən. "noʊ wʌn wɪl pæs ðoʊz ɡeɪts, fɹəm ɪnsaɪɾ əɹ aʊt. əz sun əz lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ hɝd wʌt hæd hæpənd, hi ɔɹɾɝd ðət noʊ wʌn wɑz tə bi əlaʊd tə liv ðə kip wɪθaʊɾ ɪz pɝsənəl pɝmɪʃən."

"Tripled," Ingtar said in tones of satisfaction. "No one will pass those gates, from inside or out. As soon as Lord Agelmar heard what had happened, he ordered that no one was to be allowed to leave the keep without his personal permission."

əz sun əz i hɝd . . . ? "ɪŋtʃɹ, wʌɾ əbaʊt bɪfɔɹ? wʌɾ əbaʊt ði ɝliɝ ɔɹɾɝ kipɪŋ ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn?"

As soon as he heard . . . ? "Ingtar, what about before? What about the earlier order keeping everyone in?"

"ɝliɝ ɔɹɾɝ? wʌɾ ɝliɝ ɔɹɾɝ? ɹænd, ðə kip wɑz nɑt kloʊzd əntɪl lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ hɝɾ ə ðɪs. sʌmwʌn toʊl jə ɹɔŋ."

"Earlier order? What earlier order? Rand, the keep was not closed until Lord Agelmar heard of this. Someone told you wrong."

ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd sloʊli. niðɝ ɹeɪɡən nɔɹ timə wʊɾə meɪɾ ʌp sʌmθɪŋ laɪk ðæt. ən ivən ɪf ði æmɪɝlɪn sit hæd ɡɪvən ði ɔɹɾɝ, ɪŋtʃɹ wəɾ əv tə noʊ ʌv ɪt. soʊ hu? ən haʊ? hi ɡlænst saɪdweɪz əɾ ɪŋtʃɹ, wʌndɝɪŋ ɪf ðə ʃaɪnɝən wɑz laɪɪŋ. jə ɹɪli ɑɹ ɡoʊɪŋ mæɾ ɪf jə səspɛkt ɪŋtʃɹ.

Rand shook his head slowly. Neither Ragan nor Tema would have made up something like that. And even if the Amyrlin Seat had given the order, Ingtar would have to know of it. So who? And how? He glanced sideways at Ingtar, wondering if the Shienaran was lying. You really are going mad if you suspect Ingtar.

ðeɪ wɝ ɪn ðə dʌnʒən ɡɑɹdʒɹum, naʊ. ðə sɛvɝd hɛdz ən ðə pisəz ə ðə ɡɑɹdz hæd bɪn ɹimuvd, ðoʊ ðəɹ wɝ stɪl ɹɛd smɪɹz ɑn ðə teɪbəl ən dæmp pætʃəz ɪn ðə stʃɹɔ tə ʃoʊ wɛɹ ðeɪ hæd bɪn. tu ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ ðɛɹ, plæsəd-lʊkɪŋ wɪmən wɪð bɹaʊn-fɹɪnd ʃɔlz, stʌɾiɪŋ ðə wɝdz skɹɔld ɑn ðə wɔlz, kɛɹləs ʌv wʌt ðɛɹ skɝts dʒɹæɡd θɹu ɪn ðə stʃɹɔ. itʃ hæɾ ən ɪŋkpɑɾ ɪn ə ɹaɪɾɪŋ-keɪs hʌŋ əɾ əɹ bɛlt ən wɑz meɪkɪŋ noʊts ɪn ə smɔl bʊk wɪð ə pɛn. ðeɪ nɛvɝ ivən ɡlænst ət ðə mɛn tʃɹupɪŋ θɹu.

They were in the dungeon guardroom, now. The severed heads and the pieces of the guards had been removed, though there were still red smears on the table and damp patches in the straw to show where they had been. Two Aes Sedai were there, placid-looking women with brown-fringed shawls, studying the words scrawled on the walls, careless of what their skirts dragged through in the straw. Each had an inkpot in a writing-case hung at her belt and was making notes in a small book with a pen. They never even glanced at the men trooping through.

"lʊk hɪɹ, vɛɹɪn," wʌn ə ðɛm sɛd, pɔɪntɪŋ tə ə sɛkʃən ə stoʊn kʌvɝd wɪð laɪnz ə tʃɹɑlɑk skɹɪpt. "ðɪs lʊks ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ."

"Look here, Verin," one of them said, pointing to a section of stone covered with lines of Trolloc script. "This looks interesting."

ði ʌðɝ hɝiɾ oʊvɝ, pɪkɪŋ ʌp ɹɛɾɪʃ steɪnz ɑn əɹ skɝt. "jɛs, aɪ si. ə mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ hæn ðən ðə ɹɛst. nɑɾ ə tʃɹɑlɑk. vɛɹi ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ." ʃi bɪɡæn ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪn əɹ bʊk, lʊkɪŋ ʌp ɛvɹi soʊ ɔfən tə ɹid ði æŋɡjəlɝ lɛɾɝz ɑn ðə wɔl.

The other hurried over, picking up reddish stains on her skirt. "Yes, I see. A much better hand than the rest. Not a Trolloc. Very interesting." She began writing in her book, looking up every so often to read the angular letters on the wall.

ɹænd hɝiɾ aʊt. ivən ɪf ðeɪ hæd nɑt bɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ, hi wəd nɑɾ əv wɑntəd tə ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ðə seɪm ɹum wɪð ɛniwʌn u θɔt ɹɛɾɪŋ tʃɹɑlɑk skɹɪpt ɹɪɾən ɪn hjumən blʌd wɑz "ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ."

Rand hurried out. Even if they had not been Aes Sedai, he would not have wanted to remain in the same room with anyone who thought reading Trolloc script written in human blood was "interesting."

ɪŋtʃɹ ən ɪz mɛn stɔkt ɑn əhɛd, ɪntɛn ɑn ðɛɹ duɾiz. ɹænd dɔɾəld, wʌndɝɪŋ wɛɹ i kəd ɡoʊ naʊ. ɡɛɾɪŋ bæk ɪndə ðə wɪmənz əpɑɹtməns wəd nɑt bi izi wɪθaʊɾ ɛɡwin tə hɛlp. laɪt, lɛɾ əɹ bi ɔl ɹaɪt. mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd ʃid bi ɔl ɹaɪt.

Ingtar and his men stalked on ahead, intent on their duties. Rand dawdled, wondering where he could go now. Getting back into the women's apartments would not be easy without Egwene to help. Light, let her be all right. Moiraine said she'd be all right.

læn faʊn ɪm bɪfɔɹ i ɹitʃt ðə fɝst stɛɹz liɾɪŋ ʌp. "ju kən ɡoʊ bæk tə jəɹ ɹum, ɪf jə wɑnt, ʃifɝɾɝ. mɔɪɹeɪn hæd jəɹ θɪŋz fɛtʃt fɹəm ɛɡwinz ɹum ən teɪkən tə jʊɹz."

Lan found him before he reached the first stairs leading up. "You can go back to your room, if you want, sheepherder. Moiraine had your things fetched from Egwene's room and taken to yours."

"haʊ dɪd ʃi noʊ . . . ?"

"How did she know . . . ?"

"mɔɪɹeɪn noʊz ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni θɪŋz, ʃifɝɾɝ. jə ʃəɾ ʌndɝstæn ðət baɪ naʊ. jə hæd bɛɾɝ wɑtʃ jɝsɛlf. ðə wɪmən ɑɹ ɔl tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt jə ɹʌnɪŋ θɹu ðə hɔlz, weɪvɪŋ ə sɔɹd. stɛɹɪŋ daʊn ði æmɪɝlɪn, soʊ ðeɪ seɪ."

"Moiraine knows a great many things, sheepherder. You should understand that by now. You had better watch yourself. The women are all talking about you running through the halls, waving a sword. Staring down the Amyrlin, so they say."

"laɪt! aɪm sɑɹi ðəɹ æŋɡɹi, læn, bʌɾ aɪ wɑz ɪnvaɪɾəd ɪn. ən wən aɪ hɝd ði əlɑɹm . . . bɝn mi, ɛɡwin wɑz daʊn hɪɹ!"

"Light! I am sorry they're angry, Lan, but I was invited in. And when I heard the alarm . . . burn me, Egwene was down here!"

læn pɝst ɪz lɪps θɔtfəli; ɪt wɑz ði oʊnli ɪkspɹɛʃən ɑn ɪz feɪs. "oʊ, ðəɹ nɑɾ æŋɡɹi, ɪɡzækli. ðoʊ moʊst ə ðɛm θɪŋk jə niɾ ə stʃɹɔŋ hæn tə sɛɾəl jə daʊn sʌm. fæsəneɪɾəd ɪz mɔɹ laɪk ɪt. ivən ðə leɪɾi əmælisə kæn stɑp æskɪŋ kwɛstʃənz əbaʊt ju. səm ə ðɛm ɑɹ stɑɹɾɪŋ tə bɪliv ðə sɝvəns' teɪlz. ðeɪ θɪŋk jəɹ ə pɹɪns ɪn dɪsɡaɪz, ʃifɝɾɝ. nɑɾ ə bæd θɪŋ. ðəɹ ɪz ən oʊl seɪɪŋ hɪɹ ɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz: 'bɛɾɝ tə hæv wʌn wʊmən ɑn jəɹ saɪd ðən tɛn mɛn.' ðə weɪ ðeɪ ɑɹ tɔkɪŋ əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz, ðəɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dɪsaɪd huz dɔɾɝ ɪz stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə hændəl ju. ɪf jə doʊnt wɑtʃ jəɹ stɛp, ʃifɝɾɝ, jəl faɪn jɝsɛlf mɛɹiɾ ɪndə ə ʃaɪnɝən haʊs bɪfɔɹ jə ɹilaɪz wʌɾ əz hæpənd." sʌɾənli hi bɝst aʊt læfɪŋ; ɪt lʊkt ɑd, laɪk ə ɹɑk læfɪŋ. "ɹʌnɪŋ θɹu ðə hɔlz ə ðə wɪmənz əpɑɹtməns ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə naɪt, wɛɹɪŋ ə leɪbɝɝz dʒɝkɪn ən weɪvɪŋ ə sɔɹd. ɪf ðeɪ doʊn əv jə flɑɡd, ət ðə vɛɹi lis ðəl tɔk əbaʊt jə fəɹ jɪɹz. ðeɪv nɛvɝ sin ə meɪl əz pəkjuljɝ əz ju. wʌtɛvɝ waɪf ðeɪ tʃoʊz fəɹ ju, ʃid pɹɑbli hæv jə ðə hɛɾ ə jəɹ oʊn haʊs ɪn tɛn jɪɹz, ən əv jə θɪŋkɪŋ jə hæd dʌn ɪt jɝsɛlf, bɪsaɪdz. ɪts tu bæd juv tə liv."

Lan pursed his lips thoughtfully; it was the only expression on his face. "Oh, they're not angry, exactly. Though most of them think you need a strong hand to settle you down some. Fascinated is more like it. Even the Lady Amalisa can't stop asking questions about you. Some of them are starting to believe the servants' tales. They think you're a prince in disguise, sheepherder. Not a bad thing. There is an old saying here in the Borderlands: 'Better to have one woman on your side than ten men.' The way they are talking among themselves, they're trying to decide whose daughter is strong enough to handle you. If you don't watch your step, sheepherder, you will find yourself married into a Shienaran House before you realize what has happened." Suddenly he burst out laughing; it looked odd, like a rock laughing. "Running through the halls of the women's apartments in the middle of the night, wearing a laborer's jerkin and waving a sword. If they don't have you flogged, at the very least they'll talk about you for years. They have never seen a male as peculiar as you. Whatever wife they chose for you, she'd probably have you the head of your own House in ten years, and have you thinking you had done it yourself, besides. It is too bad you have to leave."

ɹænd hæd bɪn ɡeɪpɪŋ ət ðə wɔɹɾɝ, bʌt naʊ hi ɡɹaʊld, "aɪ hæv bɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ. ðə ɡeɪts ɑɹ ɡɑɹɾəd, ən noʊ wʌn kən liv. aɪ tʃɹaɪd waɪl ɪt wɑz stɪl deɪlaɪt. aɪ kʊdn ivən teɪk ɹɛɾ aʊɾ ə ðə steɪbəl."

Rand had been gaping at the Warder, but now he growled, "I have been trying. The gates are guarded, and no one can leave. I tried while it was still daylight. I couldn't even take Red out of the stable."

"noʊ mæɾɝ, naʊ. mɔɪɹeɪn sɛn mi tə tɛl ju. jə kən liv ɛnitaɪm jə wɑn tə. ivən ɹaɪt naʊ. mɔɪɹeɪn hæɾ eɪɡəlmɝ ɪɡzɛmp jə fɹəm ði ɔɹɾɝ."

"No matter, now. Moiraine sent me to tell you. You can leave anytime you want to. Even right now. Moiraine had Agelmar exempt you from the order."

"waɪ naʊ, ən nɑɾ ɝliɝ? waɪ kʊdn aɪ liv bɪfɔɹ? wɑz ʃi ðə wʌn u hæd ðə ɡeɪts bɑɹd ðɛn? ɪŋtʃɹ sɛɾ i nu nʌθɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɛni ɔɹɾɝ tə kip pipəl ɪn bɪfɔɹ tənaɪt."

"Why now, and not earlier? Why couldn't I leave before? Was she the one who had the gates barred then? Ingtar said he knew nothing about any order to keep people in before tonight."

ɹænd θɔt ðə wɔɹɾɝ lʊk tʃɹʌbəld, bʌɾ ɔl i sɛd wɑz, "wɛn sʌmwʌn ɡɪvz jə ə hɔɹs, ʃifɝɾɝ, doʊn kəmpleɪn ðəɾ ɪɾ ɪzən əz fæst əz jud laɪk."

Rand thought the Warder looked troubled, but all he said was, "When someone gives you a horse, sheepherder, don't complain that it isn't as fast as you'd like."

"wʌɾ əbaʊɾ ɛɡwin? ən mæt? ɑɹ ðeɪ ɹɪli ɔl ɹaɪt? aɪ kæn liv əntɪl aɪ noʊ ðəɹ ɔl ɹaɪt."

"What about Egwene? And Mat? Are they really all right? I can't leave until I know they're all right."

"ðə ɡɝl ɪz faɪn. ʃɪl weɪk ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ, ən pɹɑbli nɑɾ ivən ɹɪmɛmbɝ wʌt hæpənd. bloʊz tə ðə hɛɾ ɑɹ laɪk ðæt."

"The girl is fine. She'll wake in the morning, and probably not even remember what happened. Blows to the head are like that."

"wʌɾ əbaʊt mæt?"

"What about Mat?"

"ðə tʃɔɪs ɪz ʌp tə ju, ʃifɝɾɝ. jə kən liv naʊ, əɹ təmɑɹoʊ, əɹ nɛkst wik. ɪts ʌp tə ju." hi wɔkt əweɪ, livɪŋ ɹænd stændɪŋ ðəɹ ɪn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ dip ʌndɝ fæl dæɹə kip.

"The choice is up to you, sheepherder. You can leave now, or tomorrow, or next week. It's up to you." He walked away, leaving Rand standing there in the corridor deep under Fal Dara keep.


tʃæptɝ sɛvən


CHAPTER 7

blʌd kɔlz blʌd


Blood Calls Blood

əz ðə lɪɾɝ kæɹiɪŋ mæt lɛf ði æmɪɝlɪn sits tʃeɪmbɝz, mɔɪɹeɪn kɛɹfəli ɹiɹæp ði æŋɡɹil - ə smɔl, eɪdʒ-dɑɹkən aɪvɝi kɑɹvɪŋ ʌv ə wʊmən ɪn floʊɪŋ ɹoʊbz - ɪn ə skwɛɹ ə sɪlk ən pʊɾ ɪt bæk ɪndə hɝ paʊtʃ. wɝkɪŋ təɡɛðɝ wɪð ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ, mɝdʒɪŋ ðɛɹ əbɪləɾiz, tʃænəlɪŋ ðə floʊ ʌv ðə wʌn paʊɝ tə ə sɪŋɡəl tæsk, wɑz taɪɹɪŋ wɝk ʌndɝ ðə bɛs kəndɪʃənz, ivən wɪð ði eɪɾ ʌv ən æŋɡɹil, ən wɝkɪŋ θɹu ðə naɪt wɪθaʊt slip wɑz nɑt ðə bɛs kəndɪʃənz. ən ðə wɝk ðeɪ hæd dʌn ɑn ðə bɔɪ hæd nɑt bɪn izi.

As the litter carrying Mat left the Amyrlin Seat's chambers, Moiraine carefully rewrapped the angreal - a small, age-darkened ivory carving of a woman in flowing robes - in a square of silk and put it back into her pouch. Working together with other Aes Sedai, merging their abilities, channeling the flow of the One Power to a single task, was tiring work under the best conditions, even with the aid of an angreal, and working through the night without sleep was not the best conditions. And the work they had done on the boy had not been easy.

lin dɝɛktəd ðə lɪɾɝ bɛɹɝz aʊt wɪð ʃɑɹp dʒɛstʃɝz ən ə fju kɹɪsp wɝdz. ðə tu mɛn kɛp dʌkɪŋ ðɛɹ hɛdz, nɝvəs ət biɪŋ ɝaʊn soʊ mɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ ət wʌns, ən wʌn ə ðɛm ði æmɪɝlɪn hɝsɛlf, nɛvɝ maɪn ðət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd bɪn juzɪŋ ðə paʊɝ. ðeɪ hæd weɪɾəd ɪn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ, skwɑɾɪŋ əɡɛns ðə wɔl waɪl ðə wɝk wɑz dʌn, ən ðeɪ wɝ æŋkʃəs tə bi ɡɔn fɹəm ðə wɪmənz əpɑɹtməns. mæt leɪ wɪð ɪz aɪz kloʊzd ən ɪz feɪs peɪl, bʌɾ ɪz tʃɛst ɹoʊz ən fɛl ɪn ði ivən ɹɪðəm ʌv ə dip slip.

Leane directed the litter bearers out with sharp gestures and a few crisp words. The two men kept ducking their heads, nervous at being around so many Aes Sedai at once, and one of them the Amyrlin herself, never mind that the Aes Sedai had been using the Power. They had waited in the corridor, squatting against the wall while the work was done, and they were anxious to be gone from the women's apartments. Mat lay with his eyes closed and his face pale, but his chest rose and fell in the even rhythm of a deep sleep.

haʊ wɪl ðɪs əfɛk mæɾɝz? mɔɪɹeɪn wʌndɝd. hiz nɑt nɛsəsɛɹi wɪð ðə hɔɹn ɡɔn, ən jɛt. . . .

How will this affect matters? Moiraine wondered. He is not necessary with the Horn gone, and yet. . . .

ðə dɔɹ kloʊz bɪhaɪn lin ən ðə lɪɾɝ bɛɹɝz, ən ði æmɪɝlɪn dʒɹu ən ənstɛɾi bɹɛθ. "ə næsti bɪznəs ðæt. næsti." hɝ feɪs wɑz smuð, bʌt ʃi ɹʌbd əɹ hænz təɡɛðɝ əz ɪf ʃi wɑntəd tə wɑʃ ðɛm.

The door closed behind Leane and the litter bearers, and the Amyrlin drew an unsteady breath. "A nasty business that. Nasty." Her face was smooth, but she rubbed her hands together as if she wanted to wash them.

"bʌt kwaɪɾ ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ," vɛɹɪn sɛd. ʃi hæd bɪn ðə fɔɹθ ɛɛs sədaɪ ði æmɪɝlɪn hæd tʃoʊzən fəɹ ðə wɝk. "ɪɾ ɪz tu bæd wi də nɑɾ əv ðə dæɡɝ soʊ ðə hilɪŋ kəd bi kəmplit. fəɹ ɔl wi dɪd tənaɪt, hɪl nɑt laɪv lɔŋ. mʌnθs, pɝhæps, ət bɛst." ðə θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ əloʊn ɪn ði æmɪɝlɪnz tʃeɪmbɝz. bɪɑn ði æɹoʊslɪts dɔn pɝl ðə skaɪ.

"But quite interesting," Verin said. She had been the fourth Aes Sedai the Amyrlin had chosen for the work. "It is too bad we do not have the dagger so the Healing could be complete. For all we did tonight, he will not live long. Months, perhaps, at best." The three Aes Sedai were alone in the Amyrlin's chambers. Beyond the arrowslits dawn pearled the sky.

"bʌt hɪl əv ðoʊz mʌnθs, naʊ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd ʃɑɹpli. "æn ɪf ɪt kən bi ɹitʃɹivd, ðə lɪŋk kən stɪl bi bɹoʊkən." ɪf ɪt kən bi ɹitʃɹivd. jɛs, ʌv kɔɹs.

"But he will have those months, now," Moiraine said sharply. "And if it can be retrieved, the link can still be broken." If it can be retrieved. Yes, of course.

"ɪt kən stɪl bi bɹoʊkən," vɛɹɪn əɡɹid. ʃi wɑz ə plʌmp, skwɛɹ-feɪst wʊmən, ən ivən wɪð ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɡɪft ʌv eɪɡləsnəs, ðəɹ wɑz ə tʌtʃ ʌv ɡɹeɪ ɪn əɹ bɹaʊn hɛɹ. ðət wɑz əɹ oʊnli saɪn ʌv eɪdʒ, bʌt fəɹ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪt mɛnt ʃi wɑz vɛɹi oʊld ɪndid. hɝ vɔɪs hɛl stɛɾi, ðoʊ, mætʃɪŋ əɹ smuð tʃiks. "hi hæz bɪn lɪŋk tə ðə dæɡɝ ə lɔŋ taɪm, haʊɛvɝ, əz ə θɪŋ laɪk ðət mʌs bi ɹɛkənd. ən hɪl bi lɪŋk lɔŋɡɝ jɛt, wɛðɝ ɪts faʊn əɹ nɑt. hi meɪ ɔlɹɛɾi bi tʃeɪnʒd bɪɑn ðə ɹitʃ ə fʊl hilɪŋ, ivən ɪf noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɪnʌf tə kəntæməneɪɾ ʌðɝz. sətʃ ə smɔl θɪŋ, ðət dæɡɝ," ʃi mjuzd, "bʌɾ ɪɾəl kɝʌp huɛvɝ kæɹiz ɪt lɔŋ ɪnʌf. hi hu kæɹiz ɪɾəl ɪn tɝn kɝʌp ðoʊz u kʌm ɪn kɑntækt wɪð hɪm, ən ðəl kɝʌp stɪl ʌðɝz, ən ðə heɪtʃɹəɾ ən səspɪʃən ðət dɪstʃɹɔɪd ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ, ɛvɹi mæn ən wʊmənz hæn tɝn əɡɛnst ɛvɹi ʌðɝ, wɪl bi lus ɪn ðə wɝld əɡɛn. aɪ wʌndɝ haʊ mɛni pipəl ɪt kən teɪn ɪn, seɪ, ə jɪɹ. ɪt ʃəd bi pɑsəbəl tə kælkjəleɪɾ ə ɹizənəbəl əpɹɑksəmeɪʃən."

"It can still be broken," Verin agreed. She was a plump, square-faced woman, and even with the Aes Sedai gift of agelessness, there was a touch of gray in her brown hair. That was her only sign of age, but for an Aes Sedai it meant she was very old indeed. Her voice held steady, though, matching her smooth cheeks. "He has been linked to the dagger a long time, however, as a thing like that must be reckoned. And he will be linked longer yet, whether it is found or not. He may already be changed beyond the reach of full Healing, even if no longer enough to contaminate others. Such a small thing, that dagger," she mused, "but it will corrupt whoever carries it long enough. He who carries it will in turn corrupt those who come in contact with him, and they will corrupt still others, and the hatred and suspicion that destroyed Shadar Logoth, every man and woman's hand turned against every other, will be loose in the world again. I wonder how many people it can taint in, say, a year. It should be possible to calculate a reasonable approximation."

mɔɪɹeɪn ɡeɪv ðə bɹaʊn sɪstɝ ə ɹaɪ lʊk. ənʌðɝ deɪnʒɝ kənfɹʌns ʌs, ən ʃi saʊnz əz ɪf ɪts ə pʌzəl ɪn ə bʊk. laɪt, ðə bɹaʊnz tʃɹuli ɑɹ nɑɾ əwɛɹ ə ðə wɝld əɾ ɔl. "ðɛn wi mʌs faɪn ðə dæɡɝ, sɪstɝ. eɪɡəlmɝ ɪz sɛndɪŋ mɛn tə hʌn ðoʊz u tʊk ðə hɔɹn ən slu hɪz oʊθmɛn, ðə seɪm u tʊk ðə dæɡɝ. ɪf wʌn ɪz faʊnd, ði ʌðɝ wɪl bi."

Moiraine gave the Brown sister a wry look. Another danger confronts us, and she sounds as if it is a puzzle in a book. Light, the Browns truly are not aware of the world at all. "Then we must find the dagger, Sister. Agelmar is sending men to hunt those who took the Horn and slew his oathmen, the same who took the dagger. If one is found, the other will be."

vɛɹɪn nɑɾəd, bʌt fɹaʊn ət ðə seɪm taɪm. "jɛt, ivən ɪf ɪts faʊnd, hu kən ɹɪtɝn ɪt seɪfli? huɛvɝ tʌtʃəz ɪt ɹɪsks ðə teɪn ɪf ðeɪ hændəl ɪt lɔŋ. pɝhæps ɪn ə tʃɛst, wɛl ɹæpt ən pæɾəd, bʌɾ ɪt wəd stɪl bi deɪnʒɝəs tə ðoʊz nɪɹbaɪ fəɹ ɛni ɡɹeɪt taɪm. wɪθaʊt ðə dæɡɝ ɪtsɛlf tə stʌɾi, wi kænɑt bi ʃʊɹ haʊ mʌtʃ ɪt mʌs bi ʃildɪd. bʌt jə sɔ ɪɾ ən mɔɹ, mɔɪɹeɪn. jə dɛlt wɪð ɪt, ɪnʌf fəɹ ðət jʌŋ mæn tə sɝvaɪv kæɹiɪŋ ɪɾ ən tə stɑp ɪm ɪnfɛktɪŋ ʌðɝz. jə mʌst əv ə ɡʊɾ aɪdiə ʌv haʊ stʃɹɔŋ ɪts ɪnfluəns ɪz."

Verin nodded, but frowned at the same time. "Yet, even if it is found, who can return it safely? Whoever touches it risks the taint if they handle it long. Perhaps in a chest, well wrapped and padded, but it would still be dangerous to those nearby for any great time. Without the dagger itself to study, we cannot be sure how much it must be shielded. But you saw it and more, Moiraine. You dealt with it, enough for that young man to survive carrying it and to stop him infecting others. You must have a good idea of how strong its influence is."

"ðɛɹ ɪz wʌn," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, "hu kən ɹɪtʃɹiv ðə dæɡɝ wɪθaʊt biɪŋ hɑɹm baɪ ɪt. wʌn hum wɪv ʃildɪɾ ən bʌfɝɾ əɡɛns ðət teɪn əz mʌtʃ əz ɛniwʌn kən bi. mæt kɔθən."

"There is one," Moiraine said, "who can retrieve the dagger without being harmed by it. One whom we have shielded and buffered against that taint as much as anyone can be. Mat Cauthon."

ði æmɪɝlɪn nɑɾəd. "jɛs, ʌv kɔɹs. hi kən də ɪt. ɪf i laɪvz lɔŋ ɪnʌf. ðə laɪɾ oʊnli noʊz haʊ fɑɹ ɪɾəl bi kæɹid bɪfɔɹ eɪɡəlmɝz mɛn faɪn ɪt. ɪf ðeɪ də faɪn ɪt. ən ɪf ðə bɔɪ daɪz fɝst . . . wɛl, ɪf ðə dæɡɝ ɪz lus ðət lɔŋ, wɪv ənʌðɝ wɝi." ʃi ɹʌbd əɹ aɪz taɪɹədli. "aɪ θɪŋk wi mʌs faɪn ðɪs pdən feɪn, tu. waɪ ɪz ðɪs dɑɹkfɹɛn ɪmpɔɹɾənt ɪnʌf fəɹ əm tə ɹɪsk wʌt ðeɪ dɪd tə ɹɛskju hɪm? mʌtʃ iziɝ fəɹ əm dʒʌs tə stil ðə hɔɹn. stɪl ɹɪski əz ə wɪntɝ ɡeɪl ɪn ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz, kʌmɪŋ ɪndə ðə vɛɹi kip laɪk ðæt, bʌt ðeɪ kəmpaʊndəd ðɛɹ ɹɪsk tə fɹi ðɪs dɑɹkfɹɛnd. ɪf ðə lɝks θɪŋk hiz ðəɾ ɪmpɔɹɾənt" - ʃi pɔzd, ən mɔɪɹeɪn nu ʃi wɑz wʌndɝɪŋ ɪf ɪt tʃɹuli wɑz stɪl oʊnli ðə mɹdʒɹɑl ɡɪvɪŋ kəmænz - "ðɛn soʊ mʌst wi."

The Amyrlin nodded. "Yes, of course. He can do it. If he lives long enough. The Light only knows how far it will be carried before Agelmar's men find it. If they do find it. And if the boy dies first . . . well, if the dagger is loose that long, we have another worry." She rubbed her eyes tiredly. "I think we must find this Padan Fain, too. Why is this Darkfriend important enough for them to risk what they did to rescue him? Much easier for them just to steal the Horn. Still risky as a winter gale in the Sea of Storms, coming into the very keep like that, but they compounded their risk to free this Darkfriend. If the Lurks think he is that important" - she paused, and Moiraine knew she was wondering if it truly was still only the Myrddraal giving commands - "then so must we."

"hi mʌs bi faʊnd," mɔɪɹeɪn əɡɹid, hoʊpɪŋ ðət nʌn ə ði ɝdʒənsi ʃi fɛlt ʃoʊd, "bʌɾ ɪts laɪkli hɪl bi faʊnd wɪð ðə hɔɹn."

"He must be found," Moiraine agreed, hoping that none of the urgency she felt showed, "but it is likely he will be found with the Horn."

"æz jə seɪ, dɔɾɝ." ði æmɪɝlɪn pɹɛs fɪŋɡɝz tə hɝ lɪps tə staɪfəl ə jɔn. "ænd naʊ, vɛɹɪn, ɪf jəl ɪkskjuz mi, əl dʒʌst seɪ ə fju wɝdz tə mɔɪɹeɪn ən ðən slip ə lɪɾəl. aɪ səpoʊz eɪɡəlmɝ wɪl ɪnsɪst ɑn fistɪŋ tənaɪt sɪns læs naɪt wɑz spɔɪld. jəɹ hɛlp wɑz ɪnvæljəbəl, dɔɾɝ. pliz ɹɪmɛmbɝ, seɪ nʌθɪŋ ə ðə neɪtʃɝ ə ðə bɔɪz hɝt tə ɛniwʌn. ðəɹ ɑɹ səm ə jəɹ sɪstɝz u wəd si ðə ʃædoʊ ɪn ɪm ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ə θɪŋ mɛn meɪɾ ɑn ðɛɹ oʊn."

"As you say, Daughter." The Amyrlin pressed fingers to her lips to stifle a yawn. "And now, Verin, if you will excuse me, I will just say a few words to Moiraine and then sleep a little. I suppose Agelmar will insist on feasting tonight since last night was spoiled. Your help was invaluable, Daughter. Please remember, say nothing of the nature of the boy's hurt to anyone. There are some of your sisters who would see the Shadow in him instead of a thing men made on their own."

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid tə neɪm ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ. ən pɝhæps, mɔɪɹeɪn θɔt, ðə ɹɛdz wɝ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ði oʊnli wʌnz ə hum ɪt wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi tə bi wɛɹi.

There was no need to name the Red Ajah. And perhaps, Moiraine thought, the Reds were no longer the only ones of whom it was necessary to be wary.

"aɪ wɪl seɪ nʌθɪŋ, ʌv kɔɹs, mʌðɝ." vɛɹɪn baʊd, bʌt meɪd noʊ muv təwɔɹd ðə dɔɹ. "aɪ θɔt jə maɪt wɪʃ tə si ðɪs, mʌðɝ." ʃi pʊld ə smɔl noʊtbʊk, baʊn ɪn sɑft, bɹaʊn lɛðɝ, fɹəm əɹ bɛlt. "wʌt wɑz ɹɪɾən ɑn ðə wɔlz ɪn ðə dʌnʒən. ðəɹ wɝ fju pɹɑbləmz wɪð tʃɹænzleɪʃən. moʊst wɑz ðə juʒəwəl - blæsfəmi ən boʊstɪŋ; tʃɹɑləks sim tə noʊ lɪɾəl ɛls - bʌt ðəɹ wɑz wʌn pɑɹt dʌn ɪn ə bɛɾɝ hænd. ən ɛdʒəkeɪɾəd dɑɹkfɹɛnd, əɹ pɝhæps ə mɹdʒɹɑl. ɪt kəd bi oʊnli tɔntɪŋ, jɛɾ ɪts ðə fɔɹm ə poʊətʃɹi, əɹ sɔŋ, ən ðə saʊn ə pɹɑfəsi. wi noʊ lɪɾəl ə pɹɑfəsiz fɹəm ðə ʃædoʊ, mʌðɝ."

"I will say nothing, of course, Mother." Verin bowed, but made no move toward the door. "I thought you might wish to see this, Mother." She pulled a small notebook, bound in soft, brown leather, from her belt. "What was written on the walls in the dungeon. There were few problems with translation. Most was the usual - blasphemy and boasting; Trollocs seem to know little else - but there was one part done in a better hand. An educated Darkfriend, or perhaps a Myrddraal. It could be only taunting, yet it has the form of poetry, or song, and the sound of prophecy. We know little of prophecies from the Shadow, Mother."

ði æmɪɝlɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd oʊnli ə moʊmən bɪfɔɹ nɑɾɪŋ. pɹɑfəsiz fɹəm ðə ʃædoʊ, dɑɹk pɹɑfəsiz, hæɾ ən ənfɔɹtʃənət weɪ ʌv biɪŋ fʊlfɪld əz wɛl əz pɹɑfəsiz fɹəm ðə laɪt. "ɹɛɾ ɪt tə mi."

The Amyrlin hesitated only a moment before nodding. Prophecies from the Shadow, dark prophecies, had an unfortunate way of being fulfilled as well as prophecies from the Light. "Read it to me."

vɛɹɪn ɹʌfəl θɹu ðə peɪdʒəz, ðən klɪɹɾ əɹ θɹoʊɾ ən bɪɡæn ɪn ə kɑm, lɛvəl vɔɪs.

Verin ruffled through the pages, then cleared her throat and began in a calm, level voice.

"dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪt, ʃi wɔks əɡɛn.

"Daughter of the Night, she walks again.

ði eɪntʃənt wɔɹ, ʃi jɛt faɪts.

The ancient war, she yet fights.

hɝ nu lʌvɝ ʃi siks, hu ʃæl sɝv əɹ ən daɪ, jɛt sɝv stɪl.

Her new lover she seeks, who shall serve her and die, yet serve still.

hu ʃæl stæn əɡɛnst əɹ kʌmɪŋ?

Who shall stand against her coming?

ðə ʃaɪnɪŋ wɔlz ʃæl nil.

The Shining Walls shall kneel.

blʌd fidz blʌd.

Blood feeds blood.

blʌd kɔlz blʌd.

Blood calls blood.

blʌɾ ɪz, ən blʌd wɑz, ən blʌd ʃæl ɛvɝ bi.

Blood is, and blood was, and blood shall ever be.

ðə mæn u tʃænəlz stænz əloʊn.

The man who channels stands alone.

hi ɡɪvz ɪz fɹɛnz fəɹ sækɹəfaɪs.

He gives his friends for sacrifice.

tu ɹoʊdz bɪfɔɹ hɪm, wʌn tə dɛθ bɪɑn daɪɪŋ, wʌn tə laɪf ɪtɝnəl.

Two roads before him, one to death beyond dying, one to life eternal.

wɪtʃ wɪl i tʃuz? wɪtʃ wɪl i tʃuz?

Which will he choose? Which will he choose?

wʌt hænd ʃɛltɝz? wʌt hæn sleɪz?

What hand shelters? What hand slays?

blʌd fidz blʌd.

Blood feeds blood.

blʌd kɔlz blʌd.

Blood calls blood.

blʌɾ ɪz, ən blʌd wɑz, ən blʌd ʃæl ɛvɝ bi.

Blood is, and blood was, and blood shall ever be.

luk keɪm tə ðə maʊntənz ə dum.

Luc came to the Mountains of Dhoom.

ɪsəm weɪɾəd ɪn ðə haɪ pæsəz.

Isam waited in the high passes.

ðə hʌn ɪz naʊ bɪɡʌn. ðə ʃædoʊz haʊnz naʊ kɔɹs, ən kɪl.

The hunt is now begun. The Shadow's hounds now course, and kill.

wʌn dɪd lɪv, ən wʌn dɪd daɪ, bʌt boʊθ ɑɹ.

One did live, and one did die, but both are.

ðə taɪm ə tʃeɪnʒ əz kʌm.

The Time of Change has come.

blʌd fidz blʌd.

Blood feeds blood.

blʌd kɔlz blʌd.

Blood calls blood.

blʌɾ ɪz, ən blʌd wɑz, ən blʌd ʃæl ɛvɝ bi.

Blood is, and blood was, and blood shall ever be.

ðə wɑtʃɝz weɪɾ ɑn toʊmənz hɛd.

The Watchers wait on Toman's Head.

ðə siɾ ə ðə hæmɝ bɝnz ði eɪntʃən tʃɹi.

The seed of the Hammer burns the ancient tree.

dɛθ ʃæl saʊ, ən sʌmɝ bɝn, bɪfɔɹ ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd kʌmz.

Death shall sow, and summer burn, before the Great Lord comes.

dɛθ ʃæl ɹip, ən bɑɾiz feɪl, bɪfɔɹ ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd kʌmz.

Death shall reap, and bodies fail, before the Great Lord comes.

əɡɛn ðə sid sleɪz eɪntʃən ɹɔŋ, bɪfɔɹ ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd kʌmz.

Again the seed slays ancient wrong, before the Great Lord comes.

naʊ ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd kʌmz.

Now the Great Lord comes.

naʊ ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd kʌmz.

Now the Great Lord comes.

blʌd fidz blʌd.

Blood feeds blood.

blʌd kɔlz blʌd.

Blood calls blood.

blʌɾ ɪz, ən blʌd wɑz, ən blʌd ʃæl ɛvɝ bi.

Blood is, and blood was, and blood shall ever be.

naʊ ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd kʌmz."

Now the Great Lord comes."

ðəɹ wɑz ə lɔŋ saɪləns wən ʃi fɪnɪʃt.

There was a long silence when she finished.

faɪnəli ði æmɪɝlɪn sɛd, "hu ɛls əz sin ðɪs, dɔɾɝ? hu noʊz ʌv ɪt?"

Finally the Amyrlin said, "Who else has seen this, Daughter? Who knows of it?"

"oʊnli sɹəfɛl, mʌðɝ. əz sun əz wi hæd kɑpiɾ ɪt daʊn, aɪ hæd mɛn skɹʌb ðə wɔlz. ðeɪ dɪdn kwɛstʃən; ðeɪ wɝ iɡɝ tə bi ɹɪɾ ʌv ɪt."

"Only Serafelle, Mother. As soon as we had copied it down, I had men scrub the walls. They didn't question; they were eager to be rid of it."

ði æmɪɝlɪn nɑɾəd. "ɡʊd. tu mɛni ɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz kən pʌzəl aʊt tʃɹɑlɑk skɹɪpt. noʊ nid tə ɡɪv əm sʌmθɪŋ ɛls tə wɝi oʊvɝ. ðeɪv ɪnʌf."

The Amyrlin nodded. "Good. Too many in the Borderlands can puzzle out Trolloc script. No need to give them something else to worry over. They have enough."

"wʌt dʒju meɪk ʌv ɪt?" mɔɪɹeɪn æsk vɛɹɪn ɪn ə kɛɹfəl vɔɪs. "ɪz ɪt pɹɑfəsi, dʒju θɪŋk?"

"What do you make of it?" Moiraine asked Verin in a careful voice. "Is it prophecy, do you think?"

vɛɹɪn tɪltəɾ əɹ hɛd, piɹɪŋ əɾ əɹ noʊts ɪn θɔt. "pɑsəbli. ɪts ðə fɔɹm ə səm ə ðə fju dɑɹk pɹɑfəsiz wi noʊ. ən pɑɹts ʌv ɪɾ ɑɹ klɪɹ ɪnʌf. ɪt kəd stɪl bi oʊnli ə tɔnt, ðoʊ." ʃi ɹɛstəɾ ə fɪŋɡɝ ɑn wʌn laɪn. " 'dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪt, ʃi wɔks əɡɛn.' ðət kən oʊnli min lænfɝ ɪz lus əɡɛn. əɹ sʌmwʌn wɑns əs tə θɪŋk ʃi ɪz."

Verin tilted her head, peering at her notes in thought. "Possibly. It has the form of some of the few dark prophecies we know. And parts of it are clear enough. It could still be only a taunt, though." She rested a finger on one line. " 'Daughter of the Night, she walks again.' That can only mean Lanfear is loose again. Or someone wants us to think she is."

"ðæt wəd bi sʌmθɪŋ tə wɝi ʌs, dɔɾɝ," ði æmɪɝlɪn sit sɛd, "ɪf ɪt wɝ tʃɹu. bʌt ðə fɔɹseɪkən ɑɹ stɪl baʊnd." ʃi ɡlænst ət mɔɪɹeɪn, lʊkɪŋ tʃɹʌbəl fəɹ ən ɪnstən bɪfɔɹ ʃi skuld əɹ fitʃɝz. "ivən ɪf ðə silz ɑɹ wikənɪŋ, ðə fɔɹseɪkən ɑɹ stɪl baʊnd."

"That would be something to worry us, Daughter," the Amyrlin Seat said, "if it were true. But the Forsaken are still bound." She glanced at Moiraine, looking troubled for an instant before she schooled her features. "Even if the seals are weakening, the Forsaken are still bound."

lænfɝ. ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪt. noʊwɛɹ wɑz əɹ ɹil neɪm ɹəkɔɹɾəd, bʌt ðət wɑz ðə neɪm ʃi hæd teɪkən fəɹ hɝsɛlf, ənlaɪk moʊst ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən, hu hæd bɪn neɪm baɪ ðoʊz ðeɪ bɪtʃɹeɪd. səm sɛd ʃi hæd ɹɪli bɪn ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən, nɛks tə ɪʃəml, ðə bɪtʃɹeɪɝ ə hoʊp, bʌt hæd kɛpt əɹ paʊɝz hɪɾən. tu lɪɾəl wɑz lɛft fɹəm ðət taɪm fəɹ ɛni skɑlɝ tə seɪ fəɹ sɝɾən.

Lanfear. In the Old Tongue, Daughter of the Night. Nowhere was her real name recorded, but that was the name she had taken for herself, unlike most of the Forsaken, who had been named by those they betrayed. Some said she had really been the most powerful of the Forsaken, next to Ishamael, the Betrayer of Hope, but had kept her powers hidden. Too little was left from that time for any scholar to say for certain.

"wɪð ɔl ðə fɔls dʒɹæɡənz ðəɾ ɑɹ əpɪɹɪŋ, ɪts nɑt sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ sʌmwʌn wəd tʃɹaɪ tə bɹɪŋ lænfɝ ɪndə ɪt." mɔɪɹeɪnz vɔɪs wɑz əz ənɹʌfəld əz əɹ feɪs, bʌɾ ɪnsaɪd hɝsɛlf ʃi ɹɔɪld. oʊnli wʌn θɪŋ fəɹ sɝɾən wɑz noʊn ə lænfɝ bɪsaɪd ðə neɪm: bɪfɔɹ ʃi wɛn oʊvɝ tə ðə ʃædoʊ, bɪfɔɹ luz θɝɪn tɛləmən mɛɾ aɪlaɪɛnə, lænfɝ hæd bɪn ɪz lʌvɝ. ə kɑmpləkeɪʃən wi də nɑt nid.

"With all the false Dragons that are appearing, it is not surprising someone would try to bring Lanfear into it." Moiraine's voice was as unruffled as her face, but inside herself she roiled. Only one thing for certain was known of Lanfear beside the name: before she went over to the Shadow, before Lews Therin Telamon met Ilyena, Lanfear had been his lover. A complication we do not need.

ði æmɪɝlɪn sit fɹaʊn əz ɪf ʃi hæd hæd ðə seɪm θɔt, bʌt vɛɹɪn nɑɾəd əz ɪf ɪt wɝ ɔl dʒʌst wɝdz. "ʌðɝ neɪmz ɑɹ klɪɹ, tu, mʌðɝ. lɔɹd luk, ʌv kɔɹs, wɑz bɹʌðɝ tə tɪɡɹeɪn, ðən ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ʌv ændɝ, ən i vænɪʃt ɪn ðə blaɪt. hu ɪsəm ɪz, əɹ wʌt hiz tə də wɪð luk, aɪ də nɑt noʊ, haʊɛvɝ."

The Amyrlin Seat frowned as if she had had the same thought, but Verin nodded as if it were all just words. "Other names are clear, too, Mother. Lord Luc, of course, was brother to Tigraine, then the Daughter-Heir of Andor, and he vanished in the Blight. Who Isam is, or what he has to do with Luc, I do not know, however."

"wi wɪl faɪn aʊt wʌt wi nid tə noʊ ɪn taɪm," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd smuðli. "ðɛɹ ɪz noʊ pɹuf əz jɛt ðət ðɪs ɪz pɹɑfəsi." ʃi nu ðə neɪm. ɪsəm hæd bɪn ðə sʌn ə bɹeɪən, waɪf ə leɪn mænʒɹɑɡɔɹən, huz ətɛmp tə siz ðə θɹoʊn ə mɔlkiɝ fəɹ əɹ hʌzbən hæd bɹɔt ðə tʃɹɑlɑk hɔɹdz kɹæʃɪŋ daʊn. bɹeɪən ən əɹ ɪnfən sʌn hæd boʊθ vænɪʃt wən ðə tʃɹɑləks oʊvɝɹæn mɔlkiɝ. ən ɪsəm hæd bɪn blʌd kɪn tə læn. əɹ ɪz blʌd kɪn? aɪ mʌs kip ðɪs fɹəm hɪm, əntɪl aɪ noʊ haʊ hɪl ɹiækt. əntɪl wəɹ əweɪ fɹəm ðə blaɪt. ɪf i θɔɾ ɪsəm wɝ əlaɪv. . . .

"We will find out what we need to know in time," Moiraine said smoothly. "There is no proof as yet that this is prophecy." She knew the name. Isam had been the son of Breyan, wife of Lain Mandragoran, whose attempt to seize the throne of Malkier for her husband had brought the Trolloc hordes crashing down. Breyan and her infant son had both vanished when the Trollocs overran Malkier. And Isam had been blood kin to Lan. Or is blood kin? I must keep this from him, until I know how he will react. Until we are away from the Blight. If he thought Isam were alive. . . .

" 'ðə wɑtʃɝz weɪɾ ɑn toʊmən hɛd,' " vɛɹɪn wɛn ɑn. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ ə fju hu stɪl klɪŋ tə ði oʊl bɪlif ðət ði ɑɹmiz ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ sɛn əkɹɔs ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən wɪl ɹɪtɝn wʌn deɪ, ðoʊ æftɝ ɔl ðɪs taɪm. . . ." ʃi ɡeɪv ə dɪsdeɪnfəl snɪf. "ðə də maɪɹ ævɹən, ðə wɑtʃɝz oʊvɝ ðə weɪvz, stɪl əv ə . . . kəmjunəɾi ɪz ðə bɛst wɝd, aɪ səpoʊz . . . ɑn toʊmən hɛd, ət fɑlm. ən wʌn ə ði oʊl neɪmz fəɹ ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ wɑz hæmɝ ə ðə laɪt."

" 'The Watchers wait on Toman Head,' " Verin went on. "There are a few who still cling to the old belief that the armies Artur Hawkwing sent across the Aryth Ocean will return one day, though after all this time. . . ." She gave a disdainful sniff. "The Do Miere A'vron, the Watchers Over the Waves, still have a . . . community is the best word, I suppose . . . on Toman Head, at Falme. And one of the old names for Artur Hawkwing was Hammer of the Light."

"ɑɹ jə sədʒɛstɪŋ, dɔɾɝ," ði æmɪɝlɪn sit sɛd, "ðæɾ ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz ɑɹmiz, əɹ ɹæðɝ ðɛɹ dɪsɛndəns, maɪɾ æktʃəli  ɹɪtɝn æftɝ ə θaʊzən jɪɹz?"

"Are you suggesting, Daughter," the Amyrlin Seat said, "that Artur Hawkwing's armies, or rather their descendants, might actually return after a thousand years?"

"ðɛɹ ɑɹ ɹumɝz ʌv wɔɹ ɑn ɑlməθ pleɪn ən toʊmən hɛd," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd sloʊli. "æn hɔkwɪŋ sɛn tu ʌv ɪz sʌnz, əz wɛl əz ɑɹmiz. ɪf ðeɪ dɪd sɝvaɪv ɪn wʌtɛvɝ lænz ðeɪ faʊnd, ðəɹ kəd wɛl bi mɛni dɪsɛndəns ə hɔkwɪŋ. əɹ nʌn."

"There are rumors of war on Almoth Plain and Toman Head," Moiraine said slowly. "And Hawkwing sent two of his sons, as well as armies. If they did survive in whatever lands they found, there could well be many descendants of Hawkwing. Or none."

ði æmɪɝlɪn ɡeɪv mɔɪɹeɪn ə ɡɑɹɾəd lʊk, ɑbviəsli wɪʃɪŋ ðeɪ wɝ əloʊn soʊ ʃi kəd dɪmæn tə noʊ wʌt mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz ʌp tə. mɔɪɹeɪn meɪɾ ə suðɪŋ dʒɛstʃɝ, ən əɹ oʊl fɹɛnd ɡɹɪməst ət hɝ.

The Amyrlin gave Moiraine a guarded look, obviously wishing they were alone so she could demand to know what Moiraine was up to. Moiraine made a soothing gesture, and her old friend grimaced at her.

vɛɹɪn, wɪð əɹ noʊz stɪl bɛɹiɾ ɪn əɹ noʊts, noʊɾəst nʌn ʌv ɪt. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ, mʌðɝ. aɪ daʊɾ ɪt, ðoʊ. wi noʊ nʌθɪŋ əɾ ɔl ə ðoʊz lænz ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ sɛɾ aʊt tə kɑŋkɝ. ɪts tu bæd ðə si foʊk ɹəfjuz tə kɹɔs ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən. ðeɪ seɪ ði aɪlənz ə ðə dɛd laɪ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd. aɪ wɪʃ aɪ nu wʌt ðeɪ mɛn baɪ ðæt, bʌt ðəɾ əkɝst si foʊk kloʊsəməðədnəs. . . ." ʃi saɪd, stɪl nɑt ɹeɪzɪŋ əɹ hɛd. "ɔl wɪv ɪz wʌn ɹɛfɝəns tə 'lænz ʌndɝ ðə ʃædoʊ, bɪɑn ðə sɛɾɪŋ sʌn, bɪɑn ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən, wɛɹ ði ɑɹmiz ə naɪt ɹeɪn.' nʌθɪŋ ðəɹ tə tɛl əs ɪf ði ɑɹmiz hɔkwɪŋ sɛnt wɝ ɪnʌf baɪ ðɛmsɛlvz tə dɪfit ðiz 'ɑɹmiz ə ðə naɪt,' əɹ ivən tə sɝvaɪv hɔkwɪŋz dɛθ. wʌns ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz stɑɹɾəd, ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz tu ɪntɛn ɑn kɑɹvɪŋ aʊt ðɛɹ oʊn pɑɹɾ ə hɔkwɪŋz ɛmpaɪɝ tə spɛɹ ə θɔt fəɹ ɪz ɑɹmiz əkɹɔs ðə si. ɪt simz tə mi, mʌðɝ, ðəɾ ɪf ðɛɹ dɪsɛndəns stɪl lɪvd, ən ɪf ðeɪ ɛvɝ ɪntɛndəd tə ɹɪtɝn, ðeɪ wəd nɑɾ əv weɪɾəd soʊ lɔŋ."

Verin, with her nose still buried in her notes, noticed none of it. "I don't know, Mother. I doubt it, though. We know nothing at all of those lands Artur Hawkwing set out to conquer. It's too bad the Sea Folk refuse to cross the Aryth Ocean. They say the Islands of the Dead lie on the other side. I wish I knew what they meant by that, but that accursed Sea Folk closemouthedness. . . ." She sighed, still not raising her head. "All we have is one reference to 'lands under the Shadow, beyond the setting sun, beyond the Aryth Ocean, where the Armies of Night reign.' Nothing there to tell us if the armies Hawkwing sent were enough by themselves to defeat these 'Armies of the Night,' or even to survive Hawkwing's death. Once the War of the Hundred Years started, everyone was too intent on carving out their own part of Hawkwing's empire to spare a thought for his armies across the sea. It seems to me, Mother, that if their descendants still lived, and if they ever intended to return, they would not have waited so long."

"ðɛn jə bɪliv ɪts nɑt pɹɑfəsi, dɔɾɝ?"

"Then you believe it is not prophecy, Daughter?"

"naʊ, 'ði eɪntʃən tʃɹi,' " vɛɹɪn sɛd, ɪmɝst ɪn əɹ oʊn θɔts. "ðɛɹ əv ɔlweɪz bɪn ɹumɝz - noʊ mɔɹ ðən ðət - ðət waɪl ðə neɪʃən ʌv ɑlməθ stɪl lɪvd, ðeɪ hæɾ ə bɹæntʃ ʌv ɑvɛndɪsɔɹə, pɝhæps ivən ə lɪvɪŋ sæpəlɪŋ. ən ðə bænɝ ʌv ɑlməθ wɑz 'blu fəɹ ðə skaɪ əbʌv, blæk fəɹ ði ɝθ bɪloʊ, wɪð ðə spɹɛɾɪŋ tʃɹi ʌv laɪf tə dʒɔɪn ðɛm.' ʌv kɔɹs, tæɹɑbənɝz kɔl ðɛmsɛlvz ðə tʃɹi ʌv mæn, ən kleɪm tə bi dɪsɛndəd fɹəm ɹulɝz ən noʊbəlz ɪn ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz. ən dəmɑni kleɪm dɪsɛn fɹəm ðoʊz u meɪd ðə tʃɹi ʌv laɪf ɪn ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz. ðəɹ ɑɹ ʌðɝ pɑsəbɪləɾiz, bʌt jəl noʊt, mʌðɝ, ðəɾ ət lis θɹi sɛntɝ ɝaʊn ɑlməθ pleɪn ən toʊmən hɛd."

"Now, 'the ancient tree,' " Verin said, immersed in her own thoughts. "There have always been rumors - no more than that - that while the nation of Almoth still lived, they had a branch of Avendesora, perhaps even a living sapling. And the banner of Almoth was 'blue for the sky above, black for the earth below, with the spreading Tree of Life to join them.' Of course, Taraboners call themselves the Tree of Man, and claim to be descended from rulers and nobles in the Age of Legends. And Domani claim descent from those who made the Tree of Life in the Age of Legends. There are other possibilities, but you will note, Mother, that at least three center around Almoth Plain and Toman Head."

ði æmɪɝlɪnz vɔɪs bɪkeɪm dɪsɛptɪvli dʒɛntəl. "wɪl jə meɪk ʌp jəɹ maɪnd, dɔɾɝ? ɪf ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz siɾ ɪz nɑt ɹɪtɝnɪŋ, ðən ðɪs ɪz nɑt pɹɑfəsi ən ɪt dʌzn mæɾɝ ə ɹɑɾɪd fɪʃ hɛd wʌɾ eɪntʃən tʃɹi ɪz mɛnt."

The Amyrlin's voice became deceptively gentle. "Will you make up your mind, Daughter? If Artur Hawkwing's seed is not returning, then this is not prophecy and it doesn't matter a rotted fish head what ancient tree is meant."

"aɪ kən oʊnli ɡɪv jə wʌɾ aɪ noʊ, mʌðɝ," vɛɹɪn sɛd, lʊkɪŋ ʌp fɹəm əɹ noʊts, "æn liv ðə dɪsɪʒən ɪn jəɹ hænz. aɪ bɪliv ðə læst ʌv ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz fɔɹən ɑɹmiz daɪd lɔŋ əɡoʊ, bʌt kəz aɪ bɪliv ɪt dʌz nɑt meɪk ɪt soʊ. ðə taɪm ə tʃeɪnʒ, ʌv kɔɹs, ɹəfɝz tə ði ɛn ʌv ən eɪdʒ, ən ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd - "

"I can only give you what I know, Mother," Verin said, looking up from her notes, "and leave the decision in your hands. I believe the last of Artur Hawkwing's foreign armies died long ago, but because I believe it does not make it so. The Time of Change, of course, refers to the end of an Age, and the Great Lord - "

ði æmɪɝlɪn slæp ðə teɪbəltɑp laɪk ə θʌndɝklæp. "aɪ noʊ vɛɹi wɛl u ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ ɪz, dɔɾɝ. aɪ θɪŋk jə hæd bɛɾɝ ɡoʊ naʊ." ʃi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, ən tʊk hoʊld ə hɝsɛlf vɪzəbli. "ɡoʊ, vɛɹɪn. aɪ də nɑt wɑnə bɪkʌm æŋɡɹi wɪð ju. aɪ də nɑt wɑnə fɝɡɛɾ u ɪt wɑz hæd ðə kʊks liv switkeɪks aʊɾ ət naɪt wən aɪ wɑz ə nɑvəs."

The Amyrlin slapped the tabletop like a thunderclap. "I know very well who the Great Lord is, Daughter. I think you had better go now." She took a deep breath, and took hold of herself visibly. "Go, Verin. I do not want to become angry with you. I do not want to forget who it was had the cooks leave sweetcakes out at night when I was a novice."

"mʌðɝ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, "ðɛɹ ɪz nʌθɪŋ ɪn ðɪs tə sədʒɛs pɹɑfəsi. ɛniwʌn wɪð ə lɪɾəl wɪɾ ən ə lɪɾəl nɑlədʒ kəd pʊt təɡɛðɝ əz mʌtʃ, ən noʊ wʌn əz ɛvɝ sɛd mɹdʒɹɑl də nɑɾ əv ə slaɪ wɪt."

"Mother," Moiraine said, "there is nothing in this to suggest prophecy. Anyone with a little wit and a little knowledge could put together as much, and no one has ever said Myrddraal do not have a sly wit."

"æn ə kɔɹs," vɛɹɪn sɛd kɑmli, "ðə mæn u tʃænəlz mʌs bi wʌn ə ðə θɹi jʌŋ mɛn tʃɹævlɪŋ wɪð ju, mɔɪɹeɪn."

"And of course," Verin said calmly, "the man who channels must be one of the three young men traveling with you, Moiraine."

mɔɪɹeɪn stɛɹɾ ɪn ʃɑk. nɑɾ əwɛɹ ə ðə wɝld? aɪm ə ful. bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɹilaɪzd wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ, ʃi hæd ɹitʃt aʊt tə ðə pʌlsɪŋ ɡloʊ ʃi ɔlweɪz fɛl ðəɹ weɪɾɪŋ, tə ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs. ðə wʌn paʊɝ sɝdʒd əlɔŋ əɹ veɪnz, tʃɑɹdʒɪŋ əɹ wɪð ɛnɝdʒi, mjuɾɪŋ ðə ʃin ə paʊɝ fɹəm ði æmɪɝlɪn siɾ əz ʃi dɪd ðə seɪm. mɔɪɹeɪn hæd nɛvɝ bɪfɔɹ ivən θɔɾ ʌv wildɪŋ ðə paʊɝ əɡɛnst ənʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ. wi lɪv ɪn pɛɹələs taɪmz, ən ðə wɝl hæŋz ɪn ðə bæləns, ən wʌt mʌs bi dʌn, mʌs bi dʌn. ɪt mʌst. oʊ, vɛɹɪn, waɪ dɪd juv tə pʊt jəɹ noʊz ɪn wɛɹ ɪt dʌz nɑt bɪlɔŋ?

Moiraine stared in shock. Not aware of the world? I am a fool. Before she realized what she was doing, she had reached out to the pulsing glow she always felt there waiting, to the True Source.
