The One Power surged along her veins, charging her with energy, muting the sheen of Power from the Amyrlin Seat as she did the same. Moiraine had never before even thought of wielding the Power against another Aes Sedai. We live in perilous times, and the world hangs in the balance, and what must be done, must be done. It must. Oh, Verin, why did you have to put your nose in where it does not belong?

vɛɹɪn kloʊzd əɹ bʊk ən slɪpt ɪt bæk bɪhaɪn əɹ bɛlt, ðən lʊk fɹəm wʌn wʊmən tə ði ʌðɝ. ʃi kəd nɑt bʌt bi əwɛɹ ə ðə nɪmbəs sɝaʊndɪŋ itʃ ə ðɛm, ðə laɪt ðət keɪm fɹəm tʌtʃɪŋ ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs. oʊnli sʌmwʌn tʃɹeɪn ɪn tʃænəlɪŋ hɝsɛlf kəd si ðə ɡloʊ, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ tʃæns ʌv ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ mɪsɪŋ ɪɾ ɪn ənʌðɝ wʊmən.

Verin closed her book and slipped it back behind her belt, then looked from one woman to the other. She could not but be aware of the nimbus surrounding each of them, the light that came from touching the True Source. Only someone trained in channeling herself could see the glow, but there was no chance of any Aes Sedai missing it in another woman.

ə hɪn ə sæɾəsfækʃən sɛɾəld ɑn vɛɹɪnz feɪs, bʌt noʊ saɪn ðət ʃi ɹilaɪzd ʃi hæd hɝld ə laɪtnɪŋ boʊlt. ʃi oʊnli lʊkt əz ɪf ʃi hæd faʊn ənʌðɝ pis ðət fɪɾ ɪn ə pʌzəl. "jɛs, aɪ θɔɾ ɪt mʌs bi soʊ. mɔɪɹeɪn kəd nɑt də ðɪs əloʊn, ən u bɛɾɝ tə hɛlp ðən əɹ ɡɝlhʊd fɹɛn u juz tə snik daʊn wɪð əɹ tə snɪtʃ switkeɪks." ʃi blɪŋkt. "fɝɡɪv mi, mʌðɝ. aɪ ʃəd nɑɾ əv sɛd ðæt."

A hint of satisfaction settled on Verin's face, but no sign that she realized she had hurled a lightning bolt. She only looked as if she had found another piece that fit in a puzzle. "Yes, I thought it must be so. Moiraine could not do this alone, and who better to help than her girlhood friend who used to sneak down with her to snitch sweetcakes." She blinked. "Forgive me, Mother. I should not have said that."

"vɛɹɪn, vɛɹɪn." ði æmɪɝlɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd wʌndɝɪŋli. "ju əkjuz jəɹ sɪstɝ - ən mi? - ʌv. . . . aɪ woʊn ivən seɪ ɪt. ən jə ɑɹ wɝid ðət juv spoʊkən tu fəmɪljɹli tə ði æmɪɝlɪn sit? jə bɔɹ ə hoʊl ɪn ðə boʊɾ ən wɝi ðəɾ ɪts ɹeɪnɪŋ. θɪŋk wʌt jə ɑɹ sədʒɛstɪŋ, dɔɾɝ."

"Verin, Verin." The Amyrlin shook her head wonderingly. "You accuse your sister - and me? - of. . . . I won't even say it. And you are worried that you've spoken too familiarly to the Amyrlin Seat? You bore a hole in the boat and worry that it's raining. Think what you are suggesting, Daughter."

ɪts tu leɪt fəɹ ðæt, sɪuən, mɔɪɹeɪn θɔt. ɪf wi hæd nɑt pænɪkt ən ɹitʃt fəɹ ðə sɔɹs, pɝhæps ðɛn. . . . bʌt ʃiz ʃʊɹ, naʊ. "waɪ ɑɹ jə tɛlɪŋ əs ðɪs, vɛɹɪn?" ʃi sɛɾ əlaʊd. "ɪf jə bɪliv wʌt jə seɪ, jə ʃəd bi tɛlɪŋ ɪt tə ði ʌðɝ sɪstɝz, tə ðə ɹɛdz ɪn pɝtɪkjəlɝ."

It is too late for that, Siuan, Moiraine thought. If we had not panicked and reached for the Source, perhaps then. . . . But she is sure, now. "Why are you telling us this, Verin?" she said aloud. "If you believe what you say, you should be telling it to the other sisters, to the Reds in particular."

vɛɹɪnz aɪz waɪɾənd ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. "jɛs. jɛs, aɪ səpoʊz aɪ ʃʊd. aɪ hædn θɔɾ ə ðæt. bʌt ðɛn, ɪf aɪ dɪd, jə wəd bi stɪld, mɔɪɹeɪn, ən ju, mʌðɝ, ən ðə mæn dʒɛntəld. noʊ wʌn əz ɛvɝ ɹəkɔɹɾəd ðə pɹəɡɹɛʃən ɪn ə mæn u wilz ðə paʊɝ. wən dʌz ðə mædnəs kʌm, ɪɡzækli, ən haʊ dʌz ɪt teɪk hɪm? haʊ kwɪkli dʌz ɪt ɡɹoʊ? kən i stɪl fʌŋkʃən wɪð ɪz bɑɾi ɹɑɾɪŋ ɝaʊn hɪm? fəɹ haʊ lɔŋ? ənlɛs hiz dʒɛntəld, wʌt wɪl hæpən tə ðə jʌŋ mæn, wɪtʃɛvɝ i ɪz, wɪl hæpən wɛðɝ əɹ nɑɾ aɪm ðəɹ tə pʊt daʊn ði ænsɝz. ɪf hiz wɑtʃt ən ɡaɪɾəd, wi ʃəd bi eɪbəl tə kip səm ɹɛkɝd wɪð ɹizənəbəl seɪfti, fəɹ ə taɪm, ət list. ænd, tu, ðəɹ ɪz ðə kæɹæəθən saɪkəl." ʃi kɑmli ɹɪtɝn ðɛɹ stɑɹɾəld lʊks. "aɪ əsum, mʌðɝ, ðət hiz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn? aɪ kænɑt bɪliv jə wəd də ðɪs - liv wɔkɪŋ fɹi ə mæn u kən tʃænəl - ənlɛs i wɑz ðə dʒɹæɡən."

Verin's eyes widened in surprise. "Yes. Yes, I suppose I should. I hadn't thought of that. But then, if I did, you would be stilled, Moiraine, and you, Mother, and the man gentled. No one has ever recorded the progression in a man who wields the Power. When does the madness come, exactly, and how does it take him? How quickly does it grow? Can he still function with his body rotting around him? For how long? Unless he is gentled, what will happen to the young man, whichever he is, will happen whether or not I am there to put down the answers. If he is watched and guided, we should be able to keep some record with reasonable safety, for a time, at least. And, too, there is The Karaethon Cycle." She calmly returned their startled looks. "I assume, Mother, that he is the Dragon Reborn? I cannot believe you would do this - leave walking free a man who can channel - unless he was the Dragon."

ʃi θɪŋks oʊnli ʌv ðə nɑlədʒ, mɔɪɹeɪn θɔt wʌndɝɪŋli. ðə kʌlməneɪʃən ə ðə daɪɹəs pɹɑfəsi ðə wɝl noʊz, pɝhæps ði ɛn ə ðə wɝld, ən ʃi kɛɹz oʊnli əbaʊt ðə nɑlədʒ. bʌt ʃiz stɪl deɪnʒɝəs, fəɹ ðæt.

She thinks only of the knowledge, Moiraine thought wonderingly. The culmination of the direst prophecy the world knows, perhaps the end of the world, and she cares only about the knowledge. But she is still dangerous, for that.

"hu ɛls noʊz ə ðɪs?" ði æmɪɝlɪnz vɔɪs wɑz feɪnt, bʌt stɪl ʃɑɹp. "sɹəfɛl, aɪ səpoʊz. hu ɛls, vɛɹɪn?"

"Who else knows of this?" The Amyrlin's voice was faint, but still sharp. "Serafelle, I suppose. Who else, Verin?"

"noʊ wʌn, mʌðɝ. sɹəfɛl ɪz nɑt ɹɪli ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn ɛniθɪŋ ðət sʌmwʌn hæzən ɔlɹɛɾi sɛt daʊn ɪn ə bʊk, pɹɛfɝəbli əz lɔŋ əɡoʊ əz pɑsəbəl. ʃi θɪŋks ðəɹ ɑɹ ɪnʌf oʊl bʊks ən mænjəskɹɪps ən fɹæɡməns skæɾɝd əbaʊt, lɔst əɹ fɝɡɑɾən, tə ikwəl tɛn taɪmz wʌt wɪv ɡæðɝɾ ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn. ʃi filz sɝɾən ðəɹ ɪz ɪnʌf ə ði oʊl nɑlədʒ stɪl ðəɹ tə bi faʊn fəɹ - "

"No one, Mother. Serafelle is not really interested in anything that someone hasn't already set down in a book, preferably as long ago as possible. She thinks there are enough old books and manuscripts and fragments scattered about, lost or forgotten, to equal ten times what we have gathered in Tar Valon. She feels certain there is enough of the old knowledge still there to be found for - "

"ɪnʌf, sɪstɝ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. ʃi lust əɹ hoʊld ɑn ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs, ən æftɝ ə moʊmən fɛl ði æmɪɝlɪn də ðə seɪm. ɪt wɑz ɔlweɪz ə lɔs tə fil ðə paʊɝ dʒɹeɪnɪŋ əweɪ, laɪk blʌɾ ən laɪf pɔɹɪŋ fɹəm ən oʊpən waʊnd. ə pɑɹɾ ə hɝ wɑntəd tə hoʊld ɑn, bʌɾ ənlaɪk səm ə hɝ sɪstɝz, ʃi meɪɾ ɪɾ ə pɔɪn ə sɛlf-dɪsəplən nɑt tə ɡɹoʊ tu fɑn ə ðə filɪŋ. "sɪt daʊn, vɛɹɪn, ən tɛl əs wʌt jə noʊ ən haʊ jə faʊn ɪɾ aʊt. liv aʊt nʌθɪŋ."

"Enough, Sister," Moiraine said. She loosed her hold on the True Source, and after a moment felt the Amyrlin do the same. It was always a loss to feel the Power draining away, like blood and life pouring from an open wound. A part of her wanted to hold on, but unlike some of her sisters, she made it a point of self-discipline not to grow too fond of the feeling. "Sit down, Verin, and tell us what you know and how you found it out. Leave out nothing."

əz vɛɹɪn tʊk ə tʃɛɹ - wɪð ə lʊk tə ði æmɪɝlɪn fəɹ pɝmɪʃən tə sɪɾ ɪn əɹ pɹɛzəns - mɔɪɹeɪn wɑtʃt əɹ sædli.

As Verin took a chair - with a look to the Amyrlin for permission to sit in her presence - Moiraine watched her sadly.

"ɪɾ ɪz ənlaɪkli," vɛɹɪn bɪɡæn, "ðæɾ ɛniwʌn u hæzən stʌɾid ði oʊld ɹɛkɝdz θɝoʊli wəd noʊɾəs ɛniθɪŋ ɪksɛp ðət jə wɝ bɪheɪvɪŋ ɑdli. fɝɡɪv mi, mʌðɝ. ɪt wɑz nɪɹli twɛnti jɪɹz əɡoʊ, wɪð tɑɹ vəlɑn bɪsidʒd, ðəɾ aɪ hæd maɪ fɝs klu, ən ðət wɑz oʊnli. . . .

"It is unlikely," Verin began, "that anyone who hasn't studied the old records thoroughly would notice anything except that you were behaving oddly. Forgive me, Mother. It was nearly twenty years ago, with Tar Valon besieged, that I had my first clue, and that was only. . . .

laɪt hɛlp mi, vɛɹɪn, haʊ aɪ lʌv jə fəɹ ðoʊz switkeɪks, ən fəɹ jəɹ bʊzəm tə wip ɑn. bʌɾ əl də wʌɾ aɪ mʌs du. aɪ wɪl. aɪ mʌst.

Light help me, Verin, how I loved you for those sweetcakes, and for your bosom to weep on. But I will do what I must do. I will. I must.

pɛɹɪn pɪɹɾ ɝaʊn ðə kɔɹnɝ ət ðə ɹitʃɹiɾɪŋ bæk ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ʃi smɛld ə lævəndɝ soʊp, ðoʊ moʊst wəd nɑɾ əv sɛntɪɾ ɪɾ ivən kloʊs ʌp. əz sun əz ʃi tɝn aʊɾ ə saɪt, hi hɝid fəɹ ði ɪnfɝmɝi dɔɹ. hi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi tʃɹaɪd tə si mæt wʌns, ən ðəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ - lin, hi hæd hɝd sʌmbɑɾi kɔl əɹ - hæd nɪɹli snæpt ɪz hɛɾ ɔf wɪθaʊɾ ivən lʊkɪŋ ɝaʊn tə si hu hi wɑz. hi fɛlt ənizi ɝaʊn ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɪspɛʃli ɪf ðeɪ stɑɹɾəd lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪz aɪz.

Perrin peered around the corner at the retreating back of the Aes Sedai. She smelled of lavender soap, though most would not have scented it even close up. As soon as she turned out of sight, he hurried for the infirmary door. He had already tried to see Mat once, and that Aes Sedai - Leane, he had heard somebody call her - had nearly snapped his head off without even looking around to see who he was. He felt uneasy around Aes Sedai, especially if they started looking at his eyes.

pɔzɪŋ ət ðə dɔɹ tə lɪsən - hi kəd hɪɹ noʊ fʊtstɛps daʊn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ iðɝ weɪ, ən nʌθɪŋ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə dɔɹ - hi wɛn ɪn ən kloʊzd ɪt sɔfli bɪhaɪn hɪm.

Pausing at the door to listen - he could hear no footsteps down the corridor either way, and nothing on the other side of the door - he went in and closed it softly behind him.

ði ɪnfɝmɝi wɑz ə lɔŋ ɹum wɪð waɪt wɔlz, ən ði ɛntʃɹənsəz tə ɑɹtʃɝz' bælkəniz əɾ iðɝ ɛn lɛɾ ɪn lɑts ə laɪt. mæt wɑz ɪn wʌn ə ðə nɛɹoʊ bɛdz ðət laɪn ðə wɔlz. æftɝ læs naɪt, pɛɹɪn hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd moʊst ə ðə bɛdz tə hæv mɛn ɪn ðɛm, bʌɾ ɪn ə moʊmən i ɹilaɪz ðə kip wɑz fʊl ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ. ði oʊnli θɪŋ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd nɑt kjʊɹ baɪ hilɪŋ wɑz dɛθ. tə hɪm, ðə ɹum smɛld ə sɪknəs ɛniweɪ.

The infirmary was a long room with white walls, and the entrances to archers' balconies at either end let in lots of light. Mat was in one of the narrow beds that lined the walls. After last night, Perrin had expected most of the beds to have men in them, but in a moment he realized the keep was full of Aes Sedai. The only thing an Aes Sedai could not cure by Healing was death. To him, the room smelled of sickness anyway.

pɛɹɪn ɡɹɪməst wən i θɔɾ ə ðæt. mæt leɪ stɪl, aɪz kloʊzd, hænz ənmoʊvɪŋ ətɑp ɪz blæŋkəts. hi lʊkt ɪɡzɔstəd. nɑt sɪk ɹɪli, bʌɾ əz ɪf i hæd wɝk θɹi deɪz ɪn ðə filz ən oʊnli naʊ leɪd daʊn tə ɹɛst. hi smɛld . . . ɹɔŋ, ðoʊ. ɪt wɑz nʌθɪŋ pɛɹɪn kəd pʊɾ ə neɪm tə. dʒʌst ɹɔŋ.

Perrin grimaced when he thought of that. Mat lay still, eyes closed, hands unmoving atop his blankets. He looked exhausted. Not sick really, but as if he had worked three days in the fields and only now laid down to rest. He smelled . . . wrong, though. It was nothing Perrin could put a name to. Just wrong.

pɛɹɪn sæt daʊn kɛɹfəli ɑn ðə bɛd nɛks tə mæts. hi ɔlweɪz dɪd θɪŋz kɛɹfəli. hi wɑz bɪɡɝ ðən moʊs pipəl, ən hæd bɪn bɪɡɝ ðən ði ʌðɝ bɔɪz əz lɔŋ əz i kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ. hi hæd hæd tə bi kɛɹfəl soʊ hi wəd nɑt hɝt sʌmwʌn æksədɛntəli, əɹ bɹeɪk θɪŋz. naʊ ɪt wɑz sɛkənd neɪtʃɝ tə hɪm. hi laɪk tə θɪŋk θɪŋz θɹu, tu, ən səmtaɪmz tɔk əm oʊvɝ wɪð sʌmbɑɾi. wɪð ɹænd θɪŋkɪŋ hiz ə lɔɹd, aɪ kæn tɔk tə hɪm, ən mæt sɝɾənli ɪzən gɑnə hæv mʌtʃ tə seɪ.

Perrin sat down carefully on the bed next to Mat's. He always did things carefully. He was bigger than most people, and had been bigger than the other boys as long as he could remember. He had had to be careful so he would not hurt someone accidentally, or break things. Now it was second nature to him. He liked to think things through, too, and sometimes talk them over with somebody. With Rand thinking he's a lord, I can't talk to him, and Mat certainly isn't going to have much to say.

hi hæd ɡɔn ɪndə wʌn ə ðə ɡɑɹɾənz ðə naɪt bɪfɔɹ, tə θɪŋk θɪŋz θɹu. ðə mɛmɹi stɪl meɪɾ ɪm ə lɪɾəl əʃeɪmd. ɪf i hæd nɑt ɡɔn, hi wʊɾə bɪn ɪn ɪz ɹum tə ɡoʊ wɪð ɛɡwin ən mæt, ən meɪbi hi cʊɾə kɛpt əm fɹəm biɪŋ hɝt. mɔɹ laɪkli, hi nu, hi wəd bi ɪn wʌn ə ðiz bɛdz, laɪk mæt, əɹ dɛd, bʌt ðət dɪd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ ðə weɪ hi fɛlt. stɪl, hi hæd ɡɔn tə ðə ɡɑɹɾən, ən ɪt wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðə tʃɹɑlɑk ətæk ðət wɑz wɝiɪŋ ɪm naʊ.

He had gone into one of the gardens the night before, to think things through. The memory still made him a little ashamed. If he had not gone, he would have been in his room to go with Egwene and Mat, and maybe he could have kept them from being hurt. More likely, he knew, he would be in one of these beds, like Mat, or dead, but that did not change the way he felt. Still, he had gone to the garden, and it was nothing to do with the Trolloc attack that was worrying him now.

sɝvɪŋ wɪmən hæd faʊn ɪm sɪɾɪŋ ðəɹ ɪn ðə dɑɹk, ən wʌn ə ðə leɪɾi əmælisəz ətɛndəns, ðə leɪɾi timɔɹə. əz sun əz ðeɪ keɪm əpɑn hɪm, timɔɹə sɛnt wʌn ə ði ʌðɝz ɹʌnɪŋ, ən i hæd hɝɾ əɹ seɪ, "faɪn liɑnʒɹɪn sədaɪ! kwɪkli!"

Serving women had found him sitting there in the dark, and one of the Lady Amalisa's attendants, the Lady Timora. As soon as they came upon him, Timora sent one of the others running, and he had heard her say, "Find Liandrin Sedai! Quickly!"

ðeɪ hæd stʊd ðəɹ wɑtʃɪŋ ɪm əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd θɔɾ i maɪt vænɪʃ ɪn ə pʌf ə smoʊk laɪk ə ɡlimən. ðət hæd bɪn wən ðə fɝst əlɑɹm bɛl ɹæŋ, ən ɛvɹibɑɾi ɪn ðə kip stɑɹɾəd ɹʌnɪŋ.

They had stood there watching him as if they had thought he might vanish in a puff of smoke like a gleeman. That had been when the first alarm bell rang, and everybody in the keep started running.

"liɑnʒɹɪn," hi mʌɾɝd naʊ. "ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ. əbaʊɾ ɔl ðeɪ də ɪz hʌn fəɹ mɛn u tʃænəl. jə doʊn θɪŋk ʃi bɪlivz aɪm wʌn ə ðoʊz, də ju?" mæt dɪd nɑɾ ænsɝ, ʌv kɔɹs. pɛɹɪn ɹʌbd ɪz noʊz ɹufəli. "naʊ aɪm tɔkɪŋ tə maɪsɛlf. aɪ doʊnt nid ðəɾ ɑn tɑp ʌv ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls."

"Liandrin," he muttered now. "Red Ajah. About all they do is hunt for men who channel. You don't think she believes I'm one of those, do you?" Mat did not answer, of course. Perrin rubbed his nose ruefully. "Now I'm talking to myself. I don't need that on top of everything else."

mæts aɪlɪdz flʌɾɝd. "hu . . . ? pɛɹɪn? wʌt hæpənd?" hɪz aɪz dɪd nɑɾ oʊpən ɔl ðə weɪ, ən ɪz vɔɪs saʊndəɾ əz ɪf i wɝ stɪl moʊsli əslip.

Mat's eyelids fluttered. "Who . . . ? Perrin? What happened?" His eyes did not open all the way, and his voice sounded as if he were still mostly asleep.

"doʊn jə ɹɪmɛmbɝ, mæt?"

"Don't you remember, Mat?"

"ɹɪmɛmbɝ?" mæt slipəli ɹeɪzd ə hæn təwɔɹɾ ɪz feɪs, ðən lɛɾ ɪt fɔl əɡɛn wɪð ə saɪ. hɪz aɪz bɪɡæn tə dʒɹɪft ʃʌt. "ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɛɡwin. æsk mi . . . ɡoʊ daʊn . . . si feɪn." hi læft, ən ɪt tɝn ɪndə ə jɔn. "ʃi dɪdn æsk. toʊl mi. . . . doʊnt noʊ wʌt hæpən æftɝ. . . ." hi smækt ɪz lɪps, ən ɹɪzum ðə dip, ivən bɹiðɪŋ ə slip.

"Remember?" Mat sleepily raised a hand toward his face, then let it fall again with a sigh. His eyes began to drift shut. "Remember Egwene. Asked me . . . go down . . . see Fain." He laughed, and it turned into a yawn. "She didn't ask. Told me. . . . Don't know what happened after. . . ." He smacked his lips, and resumed the deep, even breathing of sleep.

pɛɹɪn lɛp tə hɪz fiɾ əz ɪz ɪɹz kɑt ðə saʊn ʌv əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ fʊtstɛps, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊwɛɹ tə ɡoʊ. hi wɑz stɪl stændɪŋ ðəɹ bɪsaɪd mæts bɛd wən ðə dɔɹ oʊpən ən lin keɪm ɪn. ʃi stɑpt, pʊɾ əɹ fɪsts ɑn əɹ hɪps, ən lʊkt ɪm sloʊli ʌp ən daʊn. ʃi wɑz nɪɹli əz tɔl əz i wɑz.

Perrin leaped to his feet as his ears caught the sound of approaching footsteps, but there was nowhere to go. He was still standing there beside Mat's bed when the door opened and Leane came in. She stopped, put her fists on her hips, and looked him slowly up and down. She was nearly as tall as he was.

"naʊ ju," ʃi sɛd, ɪn toʊnz kwaɪət jɛt bɹɪsk, "ɑɹ ɔlmoʊst ə pɹɪɾi ɪnʌf bɔɪ tə meɪk mi wɪʃ aɪ wɑz ə ɡɹin. ɔlmoʊst. bʌɾ ɪf juv dɪstɝb maɪ peɪʃənt . . . wɛl, aɪ dɛlt wɪð bɹʌðɝz ɔlmoʊst əz bɪɡ əz jə bɪfɔɹ aɪ wɛn tə ðə taʊɝ, soʊ jə nidn θɪŋk ðoʊz ʃoʊldɝz wɪl hɛlp jə ɛni."

"Now you," she said, in tones quiet yet brisk, "are almost a pretty enough boy to make me wish I was a Green. Almost. But if you've disturbed my patient . . . well, I dealt with brothers almost as big as you before I went to the Tower, so you needn't think those shoulders will help you any."

pɛɹɪn klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊt. hæf ðə taɪm i dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd wʌt wɪmən mɛnt wən ðeɪ sɛd θɪŋz. nɑt laɪk ɹænd. hi ɔlweɪz noʊz wʌt tə seɪ tə ðə ɡɝlz. hi ɹilaɪzd i wɑz skaʊlɪŋ ən waɪpt ɪɾ əweɪ. hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə θɪŋk əbaʊt ɹænd, bʌɾ i sɝɾənli dɪd nɑt wɑnə əpsɛɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɪspɛʃli wʌn u wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə tæp əɹ fʊɾ ɪmpeɪʃənli. "ɑ . . . aɪ dɪdn dɪstɝb hɪm. hiz stɪl slipɪŋ. si?"

Perrin cleared his throat. Half the time he did not understand what women meant when they said things. Not like Rand. He always knows what to say to the girls. He realized he was scowling and wiped it away. He did not want to think about Rand, but he certainly did not want to upset an Aes Sedai, especially one who was beginning to tap her foot impatiently. "Ah . . . I didn't disturb him. He's still sleeping. See?"

"soʊ hi ɪz. ə ɡʊd θɪŋ fəɹ ju. naʊ, wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ ɪn hɪɹ? aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ tʃeɪsɪŋ jə aʊt wʌns; jə nidn θɪŋk aɪ doʊnt."

"So he is. A good thing for you. Now, what are you doing in here? I remember chasing you out once; you needn't think I don't."

"aɪ oʊnli wɑntəd tə noʊ haʊ hi ɪz."

"I only wanted to know how he is."

ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "hi ɪz slipɪŋ ɪz haʊ hi ɪz. ən ɪn ə fju aʊɝz, hɪl ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə ðət bɛd, ən jəl θɪŋk ðəɹ wɑz nɛvɝ ɛniθɪŋ ɹɔŋ wɪð hɪm."

She hesitated. "He is sleeping is how he is. And in a few hours, he will get out of that bed, and you'll think there was never anything wrong with him."

ðə pɔz meɪɾ ɪz hækəlz ɹaɪz. ʃi wɑz laɪɪŋ, sʌmhaʊ. ɛɛs sədaɪ nɛvɝ laɪd, bʌt ðeɪ dɪd nɑɾ ɔlweɪz tɛl ðə tʃɹuθ, iðɝ. hi wɑz nɑt sɝɾən wʌt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn - liɑnʒɹɪn lʊkɪŋ fəɹ hɪm, lin laɪɪŋ tə hɪm - bʌɾ i θɔɾ ɪt wɑz taɪm i ɡɑɾ əweɪ fɹəm ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ i kəd də fəɹ mæt.

The pause made his hackles rise. She was lying, somehow. Aes Sedai never lied, but they did not always tell the truth, either. He was not certain what was going on - Liandrin looking for him, Leane lying to him - but he thought it was time he got away from Aes Sedai. There was nothing he could do for Mat.

"θæŋk ju," hi sɛd. "aɪd bɛɾɝ lɛɾ ɪm slip, ðɛn. ɪkskjus mi."

"Thank you," he said. "I'd better let him sleep, then. Excuse me."

hi tʃɹaɪd tə slaɪɾ ɝaʊn əɹ tə ðə dɔɹ, bʌt sʌɾənli hɝ hænz ʃɑɾ aʊɾ ən ɡɹæbd ɪz feɪs, tɪltɪŋ ɪt daʊn soʊ ʃi kəd pɪɹ ɪndə hɪz aɪz. sʌmθɪŋ sim tə pæs θɹu hɪm, ə wɔɹm ɹɪpəl ðət stɑɹɾəd ət ðə tɑp ə hɪz hɛɾ ən wɛn tə hɪz fit, ðən keɪm bæk əɡɛn. hi pʊld ɪz hɛɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ hænz.

He tried to slide around her to the door, but suddenly her hands shot out and grabbed his face, tilting it down so she could peer into his eyes. Something seemed to pass through him, a warm ripple that started at the top of his head and went to his feet, then came back again. He pulled his head out of her hands.

"jɔɹ əz hɛlθi əz ə jʌŋ waɪld ænəməl," ʃi sɛd, pɝsɪŋ əɹ lɪps. "bʌɾ ɪf jə wɝ bɔɹn wɪð ðoʊz aɪz, aɪm ə waɪtkloʊk."

"You're as healthy as a young wild animal," she said, pursing her lips. "But if you were born with those eyes, I am a Whitecloak."

"ðeɪɹ ði oʊnli aɪz aɪ ɛvɝ hæd," hi ɡɹaʊld. hi fɛlt ə lɪɾəl əbæʃt, spikɪŋ tə ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ðət toʊn, bʌɾ i wɑz əz sɝpɹaɪzd əz ʃi wən i tʊk əɹ dʒɛnli baɪ ði ɑɹmz ən lɪftəɾ əɹ tə wʌn saɪd, sɛɾɪŋ əɹ daʊn əɡɛn aʊɾ ə hɪz weɪ. əz ðeɪ stɛɹɾ əɾ itʃ ʌðɝ, hi wʌndɝɾ ɪf ɪz aɪz wɝ əz waɪd wɪð ʃɑk əz hɝz. "ɪkskjus mi," hi sɛɾ əɡɛn, ən ɔl bʌt ɹæn.

"They're the only eyes I ever had," he growled. He felt a little abashed, speaking to an Aes Sedai in that tone, but he was as surprised as she when he took her gently by the arms and lifted her to one side, setting her down again out of his way. As they stared at each other, he wondered if his eyes were as wide with shock as hers. "Excuse me," he said again, and all but ran.

maɪ aɪz. maɪ laɪt-kɝst aɪz! ðə mɔɹnɪŋ sʌnlaɪt kɑɾ ɪz aɪz, ən ðeɪ ɡlɪntɪd laɪk bɝnɪʃt ɡoʊld.

My eyes. My Light-cursed eyes! The morning sunlight caught his eyes, and they glinted like burnished gold.

* * * ɹænd twɪstəɾ ɑn ɪz bɛd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪn ə kʌmftəɹbəl pəzɪʃən ɑn ðə θɪn mætʃɹəs. sʌnlaɪt stʃɹim θɹu ði æɹoʊslɪts, peɪntɪŋ ðə bɛɹ stoʊn wɔlz. hi hæd nɑt slɛp dʊɹɪŋ ðə ɹɪmeɪndɝ ə ðə naɪt, ən taɪɝɾ əz i wɑz, hi wɑz ʃʊɹ i kəd nɑt slip naʊ. ðə lɛðɝ dʒɝkɪn leɪ ɑn ðə flɔɹ bɪtwin ɪz bɛɾ ən ðə wɔl, bʌɾ əsaɪd fɹəm ðəɾ i wɑz fʊli dʒɹɛst, ivən tə hɪz nu buts. hɪz sɔɹd stʊd pɹɑp bɪsaɪd ðə bɛd, ən ɪz baʊ ən kwɪvɝ ɹɛstəɾ ɪn ə kɔɹnɝ əkɹɔs ðə bʌndəl kloʊks.

* * * Rand twisted on his bed, trying to find a comfortable position on the thin mattress. Sunlight streamed through the arrowslits, painting the bare stone walls. He had not slept during the remainder of the night, and tired as he was, he was sure he could not sleep now. The leather jerkin lay on the floor between his bed and the wall, but aside from that he was fully dressed, even to his new boots. His sword stood propped beside the bed, and his bow and quiver rested in a corner across the bundled cloaks.

hi kəd nɑt ɹɪd hɪmsɛlf ə ðə filɪŋ ðəɾ i ʃəd teɪk ðə tʃæns mɔɪɹeɪn hæd ɡɪvən ɪm ən liv ɪmiɾiətli. ði ɝdʒ hæd bɪn wɪð ɪm ɔl naɪt. θɹi taɪmz i hæd ɹɪzən tə ɡoʊ. twaɪs i hæd ɡɔn əz fɑɹ əz oʊpənɪŋ ðə dɔɹ. ðə hɔlz hæd bɪn ɛmpti ɪksɛp fəɹ ə fju sɝvəns duɪŋ leɪt tʃɔɹz; ðə weɪ hæd bɪn klɪɹ. bʌɾ i hæd tə noʊ.

He could not rid himself of the feeling that he should take the chance Moiraine had given him and leave immediately. The urge had been with him all night. Three times he had risen to go. Twice he had gone as far as opening the door. The halls had been empty except for a few servants doing late chores; the way had been clear. But he had to know.

pɛɹɪn keɪm ɪn, hɛd daʊn ən jɔnɪŋ, ən ɹænd sæɾ ʌp. "haʊ ɪz ɛɡwin? ən mæt?"

Perrin came in, head down and yawning, and Rand sat up. "How is Egwene? And Mat?"

"ʃiz əslip, soʊ ðeɪ tɛl mi. ðeɪ wʊdn lemi ɪndə ðə wɪmənz əpɑɹtməns tə si hɝ. mæt ɪz - " sʌɾənli pɛɹɪn skaʊld ət ðə flɔɹ. "ɪf jəɹ soʊ ɪntʃɹəstəd, waɪ hævən jə ɡɔn tə si hɪm jɝsɛlf? aɪ θɔt jə wɝ nɑɾ ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn əs ɛnimɔɹ. jə sɛd jə wɝnt." hi pʊld oʊpən ɪz dɔɹ ə ðə wɔɹdʒɹoʊb ən bɪɡæn ɹʌmɪdʒɪŋ fəɹ ə klin ʃɝt.

"She's asleep, so they tell me. They wouldn't let me into the women's apartments to see her. Mat is - " Suddenly Perrin scowled at the floor. "If you're so interested, why haven't you gone to see him yourself? I thought you were not interested in us anymore. You said you weren't." He pulled open his door of the wardrobe and began rummaging for a clean shirt.

"aɪ dɪd ɡoʊ tə ði ɪnfɝmɝi, pɛɹɪn. ðəɹ wɑz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ðɛɹ, ðət tɔl wʌn huz ɔlweɪz wɪð ði æmɪɝlɪn sit. ʃi sɛd mæt wɑz əslip, ən aɪ wɑz ɪn ðə weɪ, ən aɪ kəd kʌm bæk səm ʌðɝ taɪm. ʃi saʊndəd laɪk mæstɝ θeɪn ɔɹɾɝɪŋ ðə mɛn ət ðə mɪl. jə noʊ haʊ mæstɝ θeɪn ɪz, ɔl fʊl ə snæp ən də ɪt ɹaɪt ðə fɝs taɪm, ən də ɪt ɹaɪt naʊ."

"I did go to the infirmary, Perrin. There was an Aes Sedai there, that tall one who's always with the Amyrlin Seat. She said Mat was asleep, and I was in the way, and I could come back some other time. She sounded like Master Thane ordering the men at the mill. You know how Master Thane is, all full of snap and do it right the first time, and do it right now."

pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑɾ ænsɝ. hi dʒʌst ʃʌkt ɔf ɪz koʊɾ ən pʊld ɪz ʃɝɾ ɔf oʊvɝ ɪz hɛd.

Perrin did not answer. He just shucked off his coat and pulled his shirt off over his head.

ɹænd stʌɾid ɪz fɹɛnz bæk fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ðən dʌɡ ʌp ə læf. Rand studied his friend's back for a moment, then dug up a laugh. "You want to hear something? You know what she said to me? The Aes Sedai in the infirmary, I mean. You saw how tall she is. As tall as most men. A hand taller, and she could almost look me in the eyes. Well, she stared me up and down, and then she muttered, 'Tall, aren't you? Where were you when I was sixteen? Or even thirty?' And then she laughed, as if it was all a joke. What do you think of that?"

pɛɹɪn fɪnɪʃt tʌɡɪŋ ɑn ə klin ʃɝɾ ən ɡeɪv ɪm ə saɪɾɛlɔŋ lʊk. wɪð ɪz bɝli ʃoʊldɝz ən θɪk kɝlz, hi meɪd ɹænd θɪŋk ʌv ə hɝt bɛɹ. ə bɛɹ ðət dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd waɪ hæɾ i bɪn hɝt.

Perrin finished tugging on a clean shirt and gave him a sidelong look. With his burly shoulders and thick curls, he made Rand think of a hurt bear. A bear that did not understand why had he been hurt.

"pɛɹɪn, aɪm - "

"Perrin, I'm - "

"ɪf jə wɑnə meɪk dʒoʊks wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ," pɛɹɪn bɹoʊk ɪn, "ðæts ʌp tə ju. maɪ lɔɹd." hi bɪɡæn stʌfɪŋ ɪz ʃɝteɪl ɪndə hɪz bɹitʃɪz. "aɪ doʊn spɛn mʌtʃ taɪm biɪŋ - wɪɾi; ɪz ðət ðə wɝd? - wɪɾi wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ. bʌt ðɛn, aɪm oʊnli ə klʌmzi blæksmɪθ, ən aɪ maɪt bi ɪn sʌmbɑɾiz weɪ. maɪ lɔɹd." snætʃɪŋ ɪz koʊt fɹəm ðə flɔɹ, hi stɑɹɾəd fəɹ ðə dɔɹ.

"If you want to make jokes with Aes Sedai," Perrin broke in, "that's up to you. My Lord." He began stuffing his shirttail into his breeches. "I don't spend much time being - witty; is that the word? - witty with Aes Sedai. But then, I'm only a clumsy blacksmith, and I might be in somebody's way. My Lord." Snatching his coat from the floor, he started for the door.

"bɝn mi, pɛɹɪn, aɪm sɑɹi. aɪ wɑz əfɹeɪd, ən aɪ θɔɾ aɪ wɑz ɪn tʃɹʌbəl - meɪbi aɪ wɑz; meɪbi aɪ stɪl æm, aɪ doʊnt noʊ - ən aɪ dɪdnt wɑn jə ən mæt tə bi ɪn ɪt wɪð mi. laɪt, ɔl ðə wɪmən wɝ lʊkɪŋ fəɹ mi læs naɪt. aɪ θɪŋk ðæts pɑɹɾ ə ðə tʃɹʌbəl aɪm ɪn. aɪ θɪŋk soʊ. ən liɑnʒɹɪn. . . . ʃi. . . ." hi θɹu ʌp ɪz hænz. "pɛɹɪn, bɪliv mi, jə doʊnt wɑn ɛni pɑɹɾ ə ðɪs."

"Burn me, Perrin, I'm sorry. I was afraid, and I thought I was in trouble - maybe I was; maybe I still am, I don't know - and I didn't want you and Mat to be in it with me. Light, all the women were looking for me last night. I think that's part of the trouble I'm in. I think so. And Liandrin. . . . She. . . ." He threw up his hands. "Perrin, believe me, you don't want any part of this."

pɛɹɪn hæd stɑpt, bʌɾ i stʊd feɪsɪŋ ðə dɔɹ ən oʊnli tɝn ɪz hɛɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ ɹænd tə si wʌn ɡoʊldən aɪ. "lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ju? meɪbi ðeɪ wɝ lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ɔl ʌv ʌs."

Perrin had stopped, but he stood facing the door and only turned his head enough for Rand to see one golden eye. "Looking for you? Maybe they were looking for all of us."

"noʊ, ðeɪ wɝ lʊkɪŋ fəɹ mi. aɪ wɪʃ ðeɪ hædn bɪn, bʌɾ aɪ noʊ bɛɾɝ."

"No, they were looking for me. I wish they hadn't been, but I know better."

pɛɹɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "liɑnʒɹɪn wɑntəd mi, ɛniweɪ, aɪ noʊ. aɪ hɝd."

ɹænd fɹaʊnd. "waɪ wəd ʃi . . . ? ɪt dʌzn tʃeɪnʒ ɛniθɪŋ. lʊk, aɪ oʊpən maɪ maʊθ ən sɛd wʌɾ aɪ ʃʊdnt. aɪ dɪd nɑt min ɪt, pɛɹɪn. naʊ, pliz, wəd jə tɛl mi əbaʊt mæt?"

"hiz əslip. lin - ðæts ði ɛɛs sədaɪ - sɛɾ i wəd bi ɑn ɪz fiɾ ɪn ə fju aʊɝz." hi ʃɹʌɡd ənkʌmftəbli. "He's asleep. Leane - that's the Aes Sedai - said he would be on his feet in a few hours." He shrugged uncomfortably. "I think she was lying. I know Aes Sedai never lie, not so you can catch them, but she was lying, or keeping something back." He paused, looking at Rand sideways. "You didn't mean all that? We will leave here together? "aɪ kænt, pɛɹɪn. aɪ kæn tɛl jə waɪ, bʌɾ aɪ ɹɪli də hæv tə ɡoʊ baɪ maɪs - pɛɹɪn, weɪt!"

ðə dɔɹ slæm bɪhaɪn ɪz fɹɛnd.

The door slammed behind his friend.

ɹænd fɛl bæk ɑn ðə bɛd. "aɪ kæn tɛl ju," hi mʌɾɝd. hi paʊndɪɾ ɪz fɪst ɑn ðə saɪɾ ə ðə bɛd. "aɪ kænt." bʌt jə kən ɡoʊ naʊ, ə vɔɪs sɛɾ ɪn ðə bæk ə hɪz hɛd. ɛɡwinz gɑnə bi ɔl ɹaɪt, ən mæt wɪl bi ʌp ən ɝaʊn ɪn ən aʊɝ əɹ tu. jə kən ɡoʊ naʊ. bɪfɔɹ mɔɪɹeɪn tʃeɪnʒəz əɹ maɪnd.

Rand fell back on the bed. "I can't tell you," he muttered. He pounded his fist on the side of the bed. "I can't." But you can go now, a voice said in the back of his head. Egwene's going to be all right, and Mat will be up and around in an hour or two. You can go now. Before Moiraine changes her mind.

hi stɑɹɾəd tə sɪɾ ʌp wən ə paʊndɪŋ ɑn ðə dɔɹ meɪɾ ɪm lip tə hɪz fit. ɪf ɪt wɑz pɛɹɪn kʌm bæk, hi wəd nɑt nɑk. ðə paʊndɪŋ keɪm əɡɛn.

He started to sit up when a pounding on the door made him leap to his feet. If it was Perrin come back, he would not knock. The pounding came again.

"hu ɪz ɪt?"

"Who is it?"

læn stʃɹoʊɾ ɪn, pʊʃɪŋ ðə dɔɹ tə bɪhaɪn ɪm wɪð ɪz but hil. əz juʒəwəl, hi wɔɹ ɪz sɔɹɾ oʊvɝ ə pleɪn koʊɾ ʌv ɡɹin ðət wɑz nɪɹli ɪnvɪzəbəl ɪn ðə wʊdz. ðɪs taɪm, ðoʊ, hi hæɾ ə waɪd, ɡoʊldən kɔɹd taɪd haɪ ɝaʊn ɪz lɛft ɑɹm, ðə fɹɪn ɛnz hæŋɪŋ ɔlmoʊs tə hɪz ɛlboʊ. ɑn ðə nɑt wɑz pɪn ə ɡoʊldən kɹeɪn ɪn flaɪt, ðə sɪmbəl ə mɔlkiɝ.

Lan strode in, pushing the door to behind him with his boot heel. As usual, he wore his sword over a plain coat of green that was nearly invisible in the woods. This time, though, he had a wide, golden cord tied high around his left arm, the fringed ends hanging almost to his elbow. On the knot was pinned a golden crane in flight, the symbol of Malkier.

"ði æmɪɝlɪn sit wɑns ju, ʃifɝɾɝ. jə kænt ɡoʊ laɪk ðæt. aʊɾ ə ðət ʃɝɾ ən bɹʌʃ jəɹ hɛɹ. jə lʊk laɪk ə heɪstæk." hi dʒɝkt oʊpən ðə wɔɹdʒɹoʊb ən bɪɡæn pɔɪŋ θɹu ðə kloʊðz ɹænd mɛn tə liv bɪhaɪnd.

"The Amyrlin Seat wants you, sheepherder. You can't go like that. Out of that shirt and brush your hair. You look like a haystack." He jerked open the wardrobe and began pawing through the clothes Rand meant to leave behind.

ɹænd stʊd stɪf wɛɹ i wɑz; hi fɛlt əz ðoʊ hi hæd bɪn hɪɾ ɪn ðə hɛd wɪð ə hæmɝ. hi hæɾ ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪt, ʌv kɔɹs, ɪn ə weɪ, bʌɾ i hæd bɪn ʃʊɹ i wəd bi ɡɔn bɪfɔɹ ðə sʌmənz keɪm. ʃi noʊz. laɪt, aɪm ʃʊɹ ʌv ɪt. "wʌt dʒju min, ʃi wɑns mi? aɪm livɪŋ, læn. jə wɝ ɹaɪt. aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ tə ðə steɪbəl ɹaɪt naʊ, ɡɛt maɪ hɔɹs, ən liv."

Rand stood stiff where he was; he felt as though he had been hit in the head with a hammer. He had expected it, of course, in a way, but he had been sure he would be gone before the summons came. She knows. Light, I'm sure of it. "What do you mean, she wants me? I'm leaving, Lan. You were right. I am going to the stable right now, get my horse, and leave."

"ju ʃʊɾə dʌn ðət læs naɪt." ðə wɔɹɾɝ tɔst ə waɪt sɪlk ʃɝɾ ɑntu ðə bɛd. "noʊ wʌn ɹəfjuzəz ən ɑɾiəns wɪð ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, ʃifɝɾɝ. nɑt ðə lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ ə ðə waɪtkloʊks hɪmsɛlf. peɪdʒɹən naɪl maɪt spɛn ðə tʃɹɪp plænɪŋ haʊ tə kɪl hɝ, ɪf i kəd də ɪɾ ən ɡɛɾ əweɪ, bʌɾ i wəd kʌm." hi tɝn ɝaʊnd wɪð wʌn ə ðə haɪ-kɑlɝd koʊts ɪn ɪz hænz ən hɛld ɪɾ ʌp. "ðɪs wʌn wɪl du." tæŋɡəld, lɔŋ-θɔɹn bɹaɪɹz klaɪmd itʃ ɹɛd sliv ɪn ə θɪk, ɡoʊld-ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd laɪn, ən ɹæn ɝaʊn itʃ kʌf. ɡoʊldən hɛɹənz stʊɾ ɑn ðə kɑlɝz, wɪtʃ wɝ ɛdʒd wɪð ɡoʊld. "ðə kʌlɝ ɪz ɹaɪt, tu." hi sim tə bi əmjuzd ət sʌmθɪŋ, əɹ sæɾəsfaɪd. "kʌm ɑn, ʃifɝɾɝ. tʃeɪnʒ jəɹ ʃɝt. muv."

"You should have done that last night." The Warder tossed a white silk shirt onto the bed. "No one refuses an audience with the Amyrlin Seat, sheepherder. Not the Lord Captain Commander of the Whitecloaks himself. Pedron Niall might spend the trip planning how to kill her, if he could do it and get away, but he would come." He turned around with one of the high-collared coats in his hands and held it up. "This one will do." Tangled, long-thorned briars climbed each red sleeve in a thick, gold-embroidered line, and ran around each cuff. Golden herons stood on the collars, which were edged with gold. "The color is right, too." He seemed to be amused at something, or satisfied. "Come on, sheepherder. Change your shirt. Move."

ɹɪlʌktənli ɹænd pʊl ðə kɔɹs wʊl wɝkmənz ʃɝɾ oʊvɝ ɪz hɛd. "aɪl fil ə ful," hi mʌɾɝd. Reluctantly Rand pulled the coarse wool workman's shirt over his head. "I'll feel a fool," he muttered. "A silk shirt! I never wore a silk shirt in my life. And I never wore so fancy a coat, either, even on a feastday." Light, if Perrin sees me in that. . . . Burn me, after all that fool talk about being a lord, if he sees me in that, he'll never listen to reason.

"ju kænt ɡoʊ bɪfɔɹ ði æmɪɝlɪn sit dʒɹɛs laɪk ə ɡɹum fɹɛʃ aʊɾ ə ðə steɪbəlz, ʃifɝɾɝ. lemi si jəɹ buts. ðəl du. wɛl, ɡɛɾ ɑn wɪð ɪt, ɡɛɾ ɑn wɪð ɪt. jə doʊn kip ði æmɪɝlɪn weɪɾɪŋ. wɛɹ jəɹ sɔɹd."

"You can't go before the Amyrlin Seat dressed like a groom fresh out of the stables, sheepherder. Let me see your boots. They'll do. Well, get on with it, get on with it. You don't keep the Amyrlin waiting. Wear your sword."

"maɪ sɔɹd!" ðə sɪlk ʃɝɾ oʊvɝ ɪz hɛd mʌfəld ɹændz jɛlp. hi jæŋkt ɪt ðə ɹɛst ə ðə weɪ ɑn. "ɪn ðə wɪmənz əpɑɹtməns? læn, ɪf aɪ ɡoʊ fəɹ ən ɑɾiəns wɪð ði æmɪɝlɪn sit - ði æmɪɝlɪn sit! - wɛɹɪŋ ə sɔɹd, ʃɪl - "

"My sword!" The silk shirt over his head muffled Rand's yelp. He yanked it the rest of the way on. "In the women's apartments? Lan, if I go for an audience with the Amyrlin Seat - the Amyrlin Seat! - wearing a sword, she'll - "

"du nʌθɪŋ," læn kʌɾ ɪm ɔf dʒɹaɪli. "ɪf ði æmɪɝlɪn ɪz əfɹeɪɾ ə jə - ən ɪts smɑɹɾɝ fəɹ jə tə θɪŋk ʃi ɪzənt, kəz aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɛniθɪŋ ðət kəd fɹaɪɾən ðət wʊmən - ɪt woʊn bi fəɹ ə sɔɹd. naʊ ɹɪmɛmbɝ, jə nil wən jə ɡoʊ bɪfɔɹ hɝ. wʌn ni oʊnli, maɪnd," hi æɾəd ʃɑɹpli. "jɔɹ nɑt səm mɝtʃən kɑt ɡɪvɪŋ ʃɔɹt weɪt. meɪbi jə hæd bɛɾɝ pɹæktəs ɪt."

"Do nothing," Lan cut him off dryly. "If the Amyrlin is afraid of you - and it's smarter for you to think she isn't, because I don't know anything that could frighten that woman - it won't be for a sword. Now remember, you kneel when you go before her. One knee only, mind," he added sharply. "You're not some merchant caught giving short weight. Maybe you had better practice it."

"aɪ noʊ haʊ, aɪ θɪŋk. aɪ sɔ haʊ ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz nɛl tə kwin mɔɹɡeɪs."

"I know how, I think. I saw how the Queen's Guards knelt to Queen Morgase."

ðə ɡoʊst ʌv ə smaɪl tʌtʃt ðə wɔɹɾɝz lɪps. "jɛs, jə də ɪt dʒʌst əz ðeɪ dɪd. ðət wɪl ɡɪv əm sʌmθɪŋ tə θɪŋk əbaʊt."

The ghost of a smile touched the Warder's lips. "Yes, you do it just as they did. That will give them something to think about."

ɹænd fɹaʊnd. "waɪ ɑɹ jə tɛlɪŋ mi ðɪs, læn? jəɹ ə wɔɹɾɝ. jəɹ æktɪŋ əz ɪf jə ɑɹ ɑn maɪ saɪd."

Rand frowned. "Why are you telling me this, Lan? You're a Warder. You're acting as if you are on my side."

"aɪ æm ɑn jəɹ saɪd, ʃifɝɾɝ. ə lɪɾəl. ɪnʌf tə hɛlp jə ə bɪt." ðə wɔɹɾɝz feɪs wɑz stoʊn, ən sɪmpəθɛɾɪk wɝdz saʊndəd stʃɹeɪnʒ ɪn ðət ɹʌf vɔɪs. "wʌt tʃɹeɪnɪŋ juv hæd, aɪ ɡeɪv ju, ən əl nɑɾ əv jə ɡɹɔvəlɪŋ ən snaɪvəlɪŋ. ðə wil wivz əs ɔl ɪndə ðə pæɾɝn əz ɪt wɪlz. juv lɛs fɹiɾəm əbaʊɾ ɪt ðən moʊst, bʌt baɪ ðə laɪt, jə kən stɪl feɪs ɪɾ ɑn jəɹ fit. jə ɹɪmɛmbɝ u ði æmɪɝlɪn siɾ ɪz, ʃifɝɾɝ, ən jə ʃoʊ hɝ pɹɑpɝ ɹɪspɛkt, bʌt jə də wʌɾ aɪ tɛl ju, ən jə lʊk əɹ ɪn ði aɪ. wɛl, doʊn stæn ðəɹ ɡeɪpɪŋ. tʌk ɪn jəɹ ʃɝt."

"I am on your side, sheepherder. A little. Enough to help you a bit." The Warder's face was stone, and sympathetic words sounded strange in that rough voice. "What training you've had, I gave you, and I'll not have you groveling and sniveling. The Wheel weaves us all into the Pattern as it wills. You have less freedom about it than most, but by the Light, you can still face it on your feet. You remember who the Amyrlin Seat is, sheepherder, and you show her proper respect, but you do what I tell you, and you look her in the eye. Well, don't stand there gaping. Tuck in your shirt."

ɹænd ʃʌɾ ɪz maʊθ ən tʌkt ɪn ɪz ʃɝt. ɹɪmɛmbɝ u ʃi ɪz? bɝn mi, wʌɾ aɪ wʊdnt ɡɪv tə fɝɡɛɾ u ʃi ɪz!

Rand shut his mouth and tucked in his shirt. Remember who she is? Burn me, what I wouldn't give to forget who she is!

læn kɛpt ʌp ə ɹʌnɪŋ floʊ ʌv ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz waɪl ɹænd ʃɹʌɡd ɪndə ðə ɹɛd koʊɾ ən bʌkəld ɑn ɪz sɔɹd. wʌt tə seɪ ən tə hum, ən wʌt nɑt tə seɪ. wʌt tə du, ən wʌt nɑt. haʊ tə muv, ivən. hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ i kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɪɾ ɔl - moʊst ʌv ɪt saʊndəɾ ɑd, ən izi tə fɝɡɛt - ən i wɑz ʃʊɹ wʌtɛvɝ i fɝɡɑt wəd bi dʒʌs ðə θɪŋ tə meɪk ði ɛɛs sədaɪ æŋɡɹi wɪð hɪm. ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹən ɔlɹɛɾi. ɪf mɔɪɹeɪn toʊl ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, hu ɛls dɪd ʃi tɛl?

Lan kept up a running flow of instructions while Rand shrugged into the red coat and buckled on his sword. What to say and to whom, and what not to say. What to do, and what not. How to move, even. He was not sure he could remember it all - most of it sounded odd, and easy to forget - and he was sure whatever he forgot would be just the thing to make the Aes Sedai angry with him. If they aren't already. If Moiraine told the Amyrlin Seat, who else did she tell?

"læn, waɪ kæn aɪ dʒʌs liv ðə weɪ aɪ plænd? baɪ ðə taɪm ʃi nu aɪ wɑz nɑt kʌmɪŋ, aɪd bi ə liɡ aʊtsaɪd ðə wɔlz ən ɡæləpɪŋ."

"Lan, why can't I just leave the way I planned? By the time she knew I was not coming, I'd be a league outside the walls and galloping."

"ænd ʃiɾ əv tʃɹækɝz æftɝ jə bɪfɔɹ jə hæd ɡɔn tu. wʌt ði æmɪɝlɪn wɑns, ʃifɝɾɝ, ʃi ɡɛts." hi ədʒʌstəd ɹændz sɔɹd bɛl soʊ ðə hɛvi bʌkəl wɑz sɛntɝd. "wʌɾ aɪ də ɪz ðə bɛst aɪ kən fəɹ ju. bɪliv ɪt."

"And she'd have trackers after you before you had gone two. What the Amyrlin wants, sheepherder, she gets." He adjusted Rand's sword belt so the heavy buckle was centered. "What I do is the best I can for you. Believe it."

"bʌt waɪ ɔl ðɪs? wʌt dʌz ɪt min? waɪ də aɪ pʊt maɪ hæn oʊvɝ maɪ hɑɹɾ ɪf ði æmɪɝlɪn sit stænz ʌp? waɪ ɹɛfjus ɛniθɪŋ bʌt wɔɾɝ - nɑt ðəɾ aɪ wɑnə iɾ ə mil wɪð əɹ - ðən dʒɹɪbəl səm ɑn ðə flɔɹ ən seɪ 'ðə læn θɝsts'? ən ɪf ʃi æsks haʊ oʊld aɪ æm, waɪ tɛl əɹ haʊ lɔŋ ɪts sɪns aɪ wɑz ɡɪvən ðə sɔɹd? aɪ doʊn ʌndɝstæn hæf ʌv wʌt juv toʊl mi."

"But why all this? What does it mean? Why do I put my hand over my heart if the Amyrlin Seat stands up? Why refuse anything but water - not that I want to eat a meal with her - then dribble some on the floor and say 'The land thirsts'? And if she asks how old I am, why tell her how long it is since I was given the sword? I don't understand half of what you've told me."

"θɹi dʒɹɑps, ʃifɝɾɝ, doʊn pɔɹ ɪt. jə spɹɪŋkəl θɹi dʒɹɑps oʊnli. jə kən ʌndɝstæn leɪɾɝ soʊ lɔŋ əz jə ɹɪmɛmbɝ naʊ. θɪŋk ʌv ɪɾ əz əphoʊldɪŋ kʌstəm. ði æmɪɝlɪn wɪl də wɪð jə əz ʃi mʌst. ɪf jə bɪliv jə kən əvɔɪɾ ɪt, ðən jə bɪliv jə kən flaɪ tə ðə mun laɪk lɛn. jə kæn ɪskeɪp, bʌt meɪbi jə kən hoʊl jəɹ oʊn fəɹ ə waɪl, ən pɝhæps jə kən kip jəɹ pɹaɪd, ət list. ðə laɪt bɝn mi, aɪm pɹɑbli weɪstɪŋ maɪ taɪm, bʌɾ aɪv nʌθɪŋ bɛɾɝ tə du. hoʊl stɪl." fɹəm ɪz pɑkət ðə wɔɹɾɝ pɹədust ə lɔŋ lɛŋθ ʌv waɪd, fɹɪnd ɡoʊldən kɔɹɾ ən taɪɾ ɪɾ ɝaʊn ɹændz lɛft ɑɹm ɪn ə kɑmpləkeɪɾəd nɑt. ɑn ðə nɑɾ i fæsən ə ɹɛd-ɪnæməl pɪn, ən iɡəl wɪð ɪts wɪŋz spɹɛd. "aɪ hæd ðət meɪd tə ɡɪv ju, ən naʊ ɪz əz ɡʊɾ ə taɪm əz ɛni. ðət wɪl meɪk əm θɪŋk." ðəɹ wɑz noʊ daʊɾ əbaʊɾ ɪt, naʊ. ðə wɔɹɾɝ wɑz smaɪlɪŋ.

"Three drops, sheepherder, don't pour it. You sprinkle three drops only. You can understand later so long as you remember now. Think of it as upholding custom. The Amyrlin will do with you as she must. If you believe you can avoid it, then you believe you can fly to the moon like Lenn. You can't escape, but maybe you can hold your own for a while, and perhaps you can keep your pride, at least. The Light burn me, I am probably wasting my time, but I've nothing better to do. Hold still." From his pocket the Warder produced a long length of wide, fringed golden cord and tied it around Rand's left arm in a complicated knot. On the knot he fastened a red-enameled pin, an eagle with its wings spread. "I had that made to give you, and now is as good a time as any. That will make them think." There was no doubt about it, now. The Warder was smiling.

ɹænd lʊk daʊn ət ðə pɪn wɝidli. kɑldəzɑɹ. ðə ɹɛɾ iɡəl ə meɪnɛðɝən. "ə θɔɹn tə ðə dɑɹk wʌnz fʊt," hi mɝmɝd, "æn ə bɹæmbəl tə hɪz hænd." hi lʊkt ət ðə wɔɹɾɝ. "meɪnɛðɝənz lɔŋ dɛɾ ən fɝɡɑɾən, læn. ɪts dʒʌst ə neɪm ɪn ə bʊk, naʊ. ðəɹ ɪz oʊnli ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. wʌtɛvɝ ɛls aɪ æm, ɪm ə ʃɛpɝɾ ən ə fɑɹmɝ. ðæts ɔl."

Rand looked down at the pin worriedly. Caldazar. The Red Eagle of Manetheren. "A thorn to the Dark One's foot," he murmured, "and a bramble to his hand." He looked at the Warder. "Manetheren's long dead and forgotten, Lan. It's just a name in a book, now. There is only the Two Rivers. Whatever else I am, I'm a shepherd and a farmer. That's all."

"wɛl, ðə sɔɹd ðət kəd nɑt bi bɹoʊkən wɑz ʃæɾɝd ɪn ði ɛnd, ʃifɝɾɝ, bʌɾ ɪt fɔt ðə ʃædoʊ tə ðə læst. ðəɹ ɪz wʌn ɹul, əbʌv ɔl ʌðɝz, fəɹ biɪŋ ə mæn. wʌtɛvɝ kʌmz, feɪs ɪɾ ɑn jəɹ fit. naʊ, ɑɹ jə ɹɛɾi? ði æmɪɝlɪn sit weɪts."

"Well, the sword that could not be broken was shattered in the end, sheepherder, but it fought the Shadow to the last. There is one rule, above all others, for being a man. Whatever comes, face it on your feet. Now, are you ready? The Amyrlin Seat waits."

wɪð ə koʊl nɑɾ ɪn ðə pɪɾ ə hɪz bɛli, ɹænd fɑloʊd ðə wɔɹɾɝ ɪndə ðə hɔl.

With a cold knot in the pit of his belly, Rand followed the Warder into the hall.


tʃæptɝ eɪt


CHAPTER 8

ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn


The Dragon Reborn

ɹænd wɔk stɪf-lɛɡəɾ ən nɝvəs ət fɝst, bɪsaɪd ðə wɔɹɾɝ. feɪs ɪɾ ɑn jəɹ fit. ɪt wɑz izi fəɹ læn tə seɪ. hi hæd nɑt bɪn sʌmən baɪ ði æmɪɝlɪn sit. hi wɑz nɑt wʌndɝɪŋ ɪf i wəd bi dʒɛntəl bɪfɔɹ ðə deɪ wɑz dʌn, əɹ wɝs. ɹænd fɛlt əz ɪf i hæd sʌmθɪŋ kɑɾ ɪn ɪz θɹoʊt; hi kəd nɑt swɑloʊ, ən i wɑntəd tə, bædli.

Rand walked stiff-legged and nervous at first, beside the Warder. Face it on your feet. It was easy for Lan to say. He had not been summoned by the Amyrlin Seat. He was not wondering if he would be gentled before the day was done, or worse. Rand felt as if he had something caught in his throat; he could not swallow, and he wanted to, badly.

ðə kɔɹɪɾɝz bʌsəld wɪð pipəl, sɝvəns ɡoʊɪŋ əbaʊt ðɛɹ mɔɹnɪŋ tʃɔɹz, wɔɹiɝz wɛɹɪŋ sɔɹdz oʊvɝ laʊnʒɪŋ ɹoʊbz. ə fju jʌŋ bɔɪz kæɹiɪŋ smɔl pɹæktəs sɔɹdz steɪd nɪɹ ðɛɹ ɛldɝz, ɪməteɪɾɪŋ ðə weɪ ðeɪ wɔkt. noʊ saɪn ɹɪmeɪn ə ðə faɪɾɪŋ, bʌɾ ən ɛɹ ʌv əlɝtnəs klʌŋ ivən tə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən. ɡɹoʊn mɛn lʊk laɪk kæts weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ə pæk ə ɹæts.

The corridors bustled with people, servants going about their morning chores, warriors wearing swords over lounging robes. A few young boys carrying small practice swords stayed near their elders, imitating the way they walked. No sign remained of the fighting, but an air of alertness clung even to the children. Grown men looked like cats waiting for a pack of rats.

ɪŋtʃɹ ɡeɪv ɹænd ən læn ə pəkjuljɝ lʊk, ɔlmoʊs tʃɹʌbəld, oʊpənɪŋ ɪz maʊθ, ðən seɪɪŋ nʌθɪŋ əz ðeɪ pæs hɪm. keɪdʒɪn, tɔl ən lin ən sæloʊ, pʌmpt ɪz fɪsts oʊvɝ ɪz hɛɾ ən ʃaʊɾəd, "teɪʃɝ mɔlkiɝ! teɪʃɝ meɪnɛðɝən!" tʃɹu blʌɾ ə mɔlkiɝ. tʃɹu blʌɾ ə meɪnɛðɝən.

Ingtar gave Rand and Lan a peculiar look, almost troubled, opening his mouth, then saying nothing as they passed him. Kajin, tall and lean and sallow, pumped his fists over his head and shouted, "Tai'shar Malkier! Tai'shar Manetheren!" True blood of Malkier. True blood of Manetheren.

ɹænd dʒʌmpt. laɪt, waɪ dɪɾ i seɪ ðæt? doʊn bi ə ful, hi toʊl hɪmsɛlf. ðeɪ ɔl noʊ əbaʊt meɪnɛðɝən hɪɹ. ðeɪ noʊ ɛvɹi oʊl stɔɹi, ɪf ɪts faɪɾɪŋ ɪn ɪt. bɝn mi, aɪ hæv tə teɪk ə ɹeɪn ɑn maɪsɛlf.

Rand jumped. Light, why did he say that? Don't be a fool, he told himself. They all know about Manetheren here. They know every old story, if it has fighting in it. Burn me, I have to take a rein on myself.

læn ɹeɪzd ɪz fɪsts ɪn ɹɪplaɪ. "teɪʃɝ ʃaɪnɝ!"

Lan raised his fists in reply. "Tai'shar Shienar!"

ɪf i meɪɾ ə ɹʌn fəɹ ɪt, kəɾ i luz hɪmsɛlf ɪn ðə kɹaʊd lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə ɹitʃ ɪz hɔɹs? ɪf ʃi sɛnz tʃɹækɝz æftɝ mi. . . . wɪð ɛvɹi stɛp i ɡɹu mɔɹ tɛns.

If he made a run for it, could he lose himself in the crowd long enough to reach his horse? If she sends trackers after me. . . . With every step he grew more tense.

əz ðeɪ əpɹoʊtʃt ðə wɪmənz əpɑɹtməns, læn sʌɾənli snæpt, "kæt kɹɔsɪz ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd!"

As they approached the women's apartments, Lan suddenly snapped, "Cat Crosses the Courtyard!"

stɑɹɾəld, ɹænd ɪnstɪŋktɪvli əsum ðə wɔkɪŋ stæns əz i hæd bɪn tɔt, bæk stʃɹeɪt bʌɾ ɛvɹi mʌsəl lus, əz ɪf i hʌŋ fɹəm ə waɪɝ ət ðə tɑp ə hɪz hɛd. ɪt wɑz ə ɹɪlækst, ɔlmoʊst ɛɹəɡənt, sɔntɝ. ɹɪlækst ɑn ði aʊtsaɪd; hi sɝɾənli dɪd nɑt fil ɪɾ ɪnsaɪd. hi hæd noʊ taɪm tə wʌndɝ wʌɾ i wɑz duɪŋ. ðeɪ ɹaʊndəd ðə læs kɔɹəɾɝ ɪn stɛp wɪð itʃ ʌðɝ.

Startled, Rand instinctively assumed the walking stance as he had been taught, back straight but every muscle loose, as if he hung from a wire at the top of his head. It was a relaxed, almost arrogant, saunter. Relaxed on the outside; he certainly did not feel it inside. He had no time to wonder what he was doing. They rounded the last corridor in step with each other.

ðə wɪmən ət ði ɛntʃɹəns tə ðə wɪmənz əpɑɹtməns lʊkt ʌp kɑmli əz ðeɪ keɪm kloʊsɝ. səm sæt bɪhaɪn slæntəd teɪbəlz, tʃɛkɪŋ lɑɹdʒ lɛdʒɝz ən səmtaɪmz meɪkɪŋ ən ɛntʃɹi. ʌðɝz wɝ nɪɾɪŋ, əɹ wɝkɪŋ wɪð niɾəl ən ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi hup. leɪɾiz ɪn sɪlks kɛp ðɪs wɑtʃ, əz wɛl əz wɪmən ɪn lɪvɝi. ði ɑɹtʃt dɔɹz stʊɾ oʊpən, ənɡɑɹɾɪd ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə wɪmən. noʊ mɔɹ wɑz niɾəd. noʊ ʃaɪnɝən mæn wəɾ ɛntɝ ʌnɪnvaɪɾɪd, bʌɾ ɛni ʃaɪnɝən mæn stʊd ɹɛɾi tə dɪfɛn ðət dɔɹ ɪf niɾəd, ən i wəd bi əɡæst ət ðə nid.

The women at the entrance to the women's apartments looked up calmly as they came closer. Some sat behind slanted tables, checking large ledgers and sometimes making an entry. Others were knitting, or working with needle and embroidery hoop. Ladies in silks kept this watch, as well as women in livery. The arched doors stood open, unguarded except for the women. No more was needed. No Shienaran man would enter uninvited, but any Shienaran man stood ready to defend that door if needed, and he would be aghast at the need.

ɹændz stʌmək tʃɝnd, hɑɹʃ ən æsəd. ðəl teɪk wʌn lʊk əɾ əɹ sɔɹdz ən tɝn əs əweɪ. wɛl, ðæts wʌɾ aɪ wɑnt, ɪzən ɪt? ɪf ðeɪ tɝn əs bæk, meɪbi aɪ kən stɪl ɡɛɾ əweɪ. ɪf ðeɪ doʊn kɔl ðə ɡɑɹdz daʊn ɑn ʌs. hi klʌŋ tə ðə stæns læn hæd ɡɪvən ɪm əz i wəɾ əv tə ə floʊɾɪŋ bɹæntʃ ɪn ə flʌd; hoʊldɪŋ ɪt wɑz ði oʊnli θɪŋ ðət kɛpt ɪm fɹəm tɝnɪŋ teɪl ən ɹʌnɪŋ.

Rand's stomach churned, harsh and acid. They'll take one look at our swords and turn us away. Well, that's what I want, isn't it? If they turn us back, maybe I can still get away. If they don't call the guards down on us. He clung to the stance Lan had given him as he would have to a floating branch in a flood; holding it was the only thing that kept him from turning tail and running.

wʌn ə ðə leɪɾi əmælisəz ətɛndəns, nɪʃʊɹə, ə ɹaʊnd-feɪst wʊmən, pʊɾ əsaɪɾ əɹ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi ən stʊɾ əz ðeɪ keɪm tə ə stɑp. hɝ aɪz flɪkɝɾ əkɹɔs ðɛɹ sɔɹdz, ən əɹ maʊθ taɪɾənd, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt mɛnʃən ðɛm. ɔl ðə wɪmən stɑpt wʌt ðeɪ wɝ duɪŋ tə wɑtʃ, saɪlən ən ɪntɛnt.

One of the Lady Amalisa's attendants, Nisura, a round-faced woman, put aside her embroidery and stood as they came to a stop. Her eyes flickered across their swords, and her mouth tightened, but she did not mention them. All the women stopped what they were doing to watch, silent and intent.

"ɑnɝ tə jə boʊθ," nɪʃʊɹə sɛd, boʊɪŋ əɹ hɛd slaɪtli. ʃi ɡlænst ət ɹænd, soʊ kwɪkli hi wɑz ɔlmoʊs nɑt ʃʊɹ i hæd sin ɪt; ɪt ɹimaɪndəɾ ɪm ʌv wʌt pɛɹɪn hæd sɛd. "ði æmɪɝlɪn siɾ əweɪts ju." ʃi moʊʃənd, ən tu ʌðɝ leɪɾiz - nɑt sɝvəns; ðeɪ wɝ biɪŋ ɑnɝd - stɛp fɔɹwɝd fəɹ ɛskɔɹts. ðə wɪmən baʊd, ə hɛɹ mɔɹ ðən nɪʃʊɹə hæd, ən moʊʃən əm θɹu ði ɑɹtʃweɪ. ðeɪ boʊθ ɡeɪv ɹænd ə saɪɾɛlɔŋ ɡlæns, ðən dɪd nɑt lʊk əɾ ɪm əɡɛn.

"Honor to you both," Nisura said, bowing her head slightly. She glanced at Rand, so quickly he was almost not sure he had seen it; it reminded him of what Perrin had said. "The Amyrlin Seat awaits you." She motioned, and two other ladies - not servants; they were being honored - stepped forward for escorts. The women bowed, a hair more than Nisura had, and motioned them through the archway. They both gave Rand a sidelong glance, then did not look at him again.

wɝ ðeɪ lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ɔl ʌv ʌs, əɹ dʒʌs mi? waɪ ɔl ʌv ʌs?

Were they looking for all of us, or just me? Why all of us?

ɪnsaɪd, ðeɪ ɡɑt ðə lʊks ɹænd ɪkspɛktəd - tu mɛn ɪn ðə wɪmənz əpɑɹtməns wɛɹ mɛn wɝ ɹɛɹ - ən ðɛɹ sɔɹdz kɑz mɔɹ ðən wʌn ɹeɪzd aɪbɹaʊ, bʌt nʌn ə ðə wɪmən spoʊk. ðə tu mɛn lɛf nɑts ə kɑnvɝseɪʃən ɪn ðɛɹ pæθ, sɑf mɝmɝz tu loʊ fəɹ ɹænd tə meɪk aʊt. læn stʃɹoʊɾ əlɔŋ əz ɪf i dɪd nɑɾ ivən noʊɾəs. ɹænd kɛpt peɪs bɪhaɪn ðɛɹ ɛskɔɹts ən wɪʃt i kəd hɪɹ.

Inside, they got the looks Rand expected - two men in the women's apartments where men were rare - and their swords caused more than one raised eyebrow, but none of the women spoke. The two men left knots of conversation in their path, soft murmurs too low for Rand to make out. Lan strode along as if he did not even notice. Rand kept pace behind their escorts and wished he could hear.

ən ðən ðeɪ ɹitʃt ði æmɪɝlɪn sits tʃeɪmbɝz, wɪð θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ðə hɔl aʊtsaɪd ðə dɔɹ. ðə tɔl ɛɛs sədaɪ, lin, hɛld əɹ ɡoʊldən-fleɪm stæf. ɹænd dɪd nɑt noʊ ði ʌðɝ tu, wʌn ə ðə waɪɾ ədʒɑ ən wʌn jɛloʊ baɪ ðɛɹ fɹɪnʒ. hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðɛɹ feɪsəz, ðoʊ, stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪm əz i hæd ɹʌn θɹu ðiz seɪm hɔlz. smuð ɛɛs sədaɪ feɪsəz, wɪð noʊɪŋ aɪz. ðeɪ stʌɾid ɪm wɪð ɑɹtʃt aɪbɹaʊz ən pɝs lɪps. ðə wɪmən u hæd bɹɔt læn ən ɹænd kɝtsid, hændɪŋ əm oʊvɝ tə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ.

And then they reached the Amyrlin Seat's chambers, with three Aes Sedai in the hall outside the door. The tall Aes Sedai, Leane, held her golden-flamed staff. Rand did not know the other two, one of the White Ajah and one Yellow by their fringe. He remembered their faces, though, staring at him as he had run through these same halls. Smooth Aes Sedai faces, with knowing eyes. They studied him with arched eyebrows and pursed lips. The women who had brought Lan and Rand curtsied, handing them over to the Aes Sedai.

lin lʊkt ɹænd oʊvɝ wɪð ə slaɪt smaɪl. dɪspaɪt ðə smaɪl, hɝ vɔɪs hæɾ ə snæp tə ɪt. "wʌɾ əv jə bɹɔt ði æmɪɝlɪn sit tədeɪ, læn ɡeɪɾɪn? ə jʌŋ laɪən? bɛɾɝ jə doʊn lɛɾ ɛni ɡɹinz si ðɪs wʌn, əɹ wʌn ə ðɛm wɪl bɑn ɪm bɪfɔɹ i kən teɪk ə bɹɛθ. ɡɹinz laɪk tə bɑn əm jʌŋ."

Leane looked Rand over with a slight smile. Despite the smile, her voice had a snap to it. "What have you brought the Amyrlin Seat today, Lan Gaidin? A young lion? Better you don't let any Greens see this one, or one of them will bond him before he can take a breath. Greens like to bond them young."

ɹænd wʌndɝɾ ɪf ɪt wɑz ɹɪli pɑsəbəl tə swɛɾ ɪnsaɪd jəɹ skɪn. hi fɛlt əz ɪf i wɑz. hi wɑntəd tə lʊk ət læn, bʌɾ i ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðɪs pɑɹɾ ə ðə wɔɹɾɝz ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz. "aɪ æm ɹænd ælθɹ, sʌn ə tæm ælθɹ, ʌv ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, wɪtʃ wʌns wɑz meɪnɛðɝən. əz aɪ hæv bɪn sʌmən baɪ ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, lin sədaɪ, soʊ də aɪ kʌm. aɪ stæn ɹɛɾi." hi wɑz sɝpɹaɪz ðəɾ ɪz vɔɪs dɪd nɑt ʃeɪk wʌns.

Rand wondered if it was really possible to sweat inside your skin. He felt as if he was. He wanted to look at Lan, but he remembered this part of the Warder's instructions. "I am Rand al'Thor, son of Tam al'Thor, of the Two Rivers, which once was Manetheren. As I have been summoned by the Amyrlin Seat, Leane Sedai, so do I come. I stand ready." He was surprised that his voice did not shake once.

lin blɪŋkt, ən əɹ smaɪl feɪɾəd tə ə θɔtfəl lʊk. "ðɪs ɪz səpoʊz tə bi ə ʃɛpɝd, læn ɡeɪɾɪn? hi wɑz nɑt soʊ ʃʊɹ ə hɪmsɛlf ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ."

Leane blinked, and her smile faded to a thoughtful look. "This is supposed to be a shepherd, Lan Gaidin? He was not so sure of himself this morning."

"hi ɪz ə mæn, lin sədaɪ," læn sɛd fɝmli, "noʊ mɔɹ, ən noʊ lɛs. wəɹ wʌt wi ɑɹ."

"He is a man, Leane Sedai," Lan said firmly, "no more, and no less. We are what we are."

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "ðə wɝld ɡɹoʊz stʃɹeɪnʒɝ ɛvɹi deɪ. aɪ səpoʊz ðə blæksmɪθ wɪl wɛɹ ə kɹaʊn ən spik ɪn haɪ tʃænt. weɪt hɪɹ." ʃi vænɪʃt ɪnsaɪd tə ənaʊns ðɛm.

The Aes Sedai shook her head. "The world grows stranger every day. I suppose the blacksmith will wear a crown and speak in High Chant. Wait here." She vanished inside to announce them.

ʃi wɑz oʊnli ɡɔn ə fju moʊməns, bʌt ɹænd wɑz ənkʌmftəbli əwɛɹ ə ði aɪz ə ðə ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ. hi tʃɹaɪd tə ɹɪtɝn ðɛɹ ɡeɪz lɛvəli, ðə weɪ læn hæd toʊld ɪm tə, ən ðeɪ pʊt ðɛɹ hɛdz təɡɛðɝ, wɪspɝɪŋ. wʌɾ ɑɹ ðeɪ seɪɪŋ? wʌt də ðeɪ noʊ? laɪt, ɑɹ ðeɪ gɑnə dʒɛntəl mi? wɑz ðət wʌt læn mɛn əbaʊt feɪsɪŋ wʌtɛvɝ kʌmz?

She was only gone a few moments, but Rand was uncomfortably aware of the eyes of the remaining Aes Sedai. He tried to return their gaze levelly, the way Lan had told him to, and they put their heads together, whispering. What are they saying? What do they know? Light, are they going to gentle me? Was that what Lan meant about facing whatever comes?

lin ɹɪtɝnd, moʊʃənɪŋ ɹænd tə ɡoʊ ɪn. wən læn stɑɹɾəd tə fɑloʊ, ʃi θɹʌst əɹ stæf əkɹɔs ɪz tʃɛst, stɑpɪŋ hɪm. "nɑt ju, læn ɡeɪɾɪn. mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ hæz ə tæsk fəɹ ju. jəɹ laɪən kʌb wɪl bi seɪf ɪnʌf baɪ hɪmsɛlf."

Leane returned, motioning Rand to go in. When Lan started to follow, she thrust her staff across his chest, stopping him. "Not you, Lan Gaidin. Moiraine Sedai has a task for you. Your lion cub will be safe enough by himself."

ðə dɔɹ swʌŋ ʃʌt bɪhaɪn ɹænd, bʌt nɑt bɪfɔɹ i hɝd lænz vɔɪs, fɪɹs ən stʃɹɔŋ, bʌt loʊ fəɹ ɪz ɪɹ əloʊn. "teɪʃɝ meɪnɛðɝən!"

The door swung shut behind Rand, but not before he heard Lan's voice, fierce and strong, but low for his ear alone. "Tai'shar Manetheren!"

mɔɪɹeɪn sæt tə wʌn saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum, ən wʌn ə ðə bɹaʊn ɛɛs sədaɪ hi hæd sin ɪn ðə dʌnʒən sæt tə ði ʌðɝ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðə wʊmən ɪn ðə tɔl tʃɛɹ bɪhaɪn ðə waɪd teɪbəl u hɛld ɪz aɪz. ðə kɝɾənz hæd bɪn pɑɹʃəli dʒɹɔn oʊvɝ ði æɹoʊslɪts, bʌt ðə ɡæps lɛɾ ɪn ɪnʌf laɪt bɪhaɪn əɹ tə meɪk əɹ feɪs hɑɹd tə si klɪɹli. hi stɪl ɹɛkəɡnaɪz hɝ, ðoʊ. ði æmɪɝlɪn sit.

Moiraine sat to one side of the room, and one of the Brown Aes Sedai he had seen in the dungeon sat to the other, but it was the woman in the tall chair behind the wide table who held his eyes. The curtains had been partially drawn over the arrowslits, but the gaps let in enough light behind her to make her face hard to see clearly. He still recognized her, though. The Amyrlin Seat.

kwɪkli hi dʒɹɑp tə wʌn ni, lɛf hæn ɑn sɔɹd hɪlt, ɹaɪt fɪs pɹɛs tə ðə pæɾɝnd ɹʌɡ, ən baʊɾ ɪz hɛd. "æz juv sʌmən mi, mʌðɝ, soʊ hæv aɪ kʌm. aɪ stæn ɹɛɾi." hi lɪftəɾ ɪz hɛɾ ɪn taɪm tə si hɝ aɪbɹaʊz ɹaɪz.

Quickly he dropped to one knee, left hand on sword hilt, right fist pressed to the patterned rug, and bowed his head. "As you have summoned me, Mother, so have I come. I stand ready." He lifted his head in time to see her eyebrows rise.

"du jə naʊ, bɔɪ?" ʃi saʊndəɾ ɔlmoʊst əmjuzd. ən sʌmθɪŋ ɛls i kəd nɑt meɪk aʊt. ʃi sɝɾənli dɪd nɑt lʊk əmjuzd. "stæn ʌp, bɔɪ, ən lemi hæv ə lʊk ət ju."

"Do you now, boy?" She sounded almost amused. And something else he could not make out. She certainly did not look amused. "Stand up, boy, and let me have a look at you."

hi stʃɹeɪɾənd ən tʃɹaɪd tə kip ɪz feɪs ɹɪlækst. ɪt wɑz ən ɛfɝt nɑt tə klɛntʃ ɪz hænz. θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ. haʊ mɛni dʌz ɪt teɪk tə dʒɛntəl ə mæn? ðeɪ sɛn ə dʌzən əɹ mɔɹ æftɝ lɑɡən. wəd mɔɪɹeɪn də ðət tə mi? hi mɛt ði æmɪɝlɪn sits lʊk aɪ tə aɪ. ʃi dɪd nɑt blɪŋk.

He straightened and tried to keep his face relaxed. It was an effort not to clench his hands. Three Aes Sedai. How many does it take to gentle a man? They sent a dozen or more after Logain. Would Moiraine do that to me? He met the Amyrlin Seat's look eye to eye. She did not blink.

"sɪt, bɔɪ," ʃi sɛd faɪnəli, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ tə ə læɾɝ-bæk tʃɛɹ ðət hæd bɪn pʊld ɝaʊn skwɛɹli ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə teɪbəl. "ðɪs wɪl nɑt bi ʃɔɹt, aɪ fɪɹ."

"Sit, boy," she said finally, gesturing to a ladder-back chair that had been pulled around squarely in front of the table. "This will not be short, I fear."

"θæŋk ju, mʌðɝ." hi baʊɾ ɪz hɛd, ðɛn, əz læn hæd toʊl hɪm, ɡlænst ət ðə tʃɛɹ ən tʌtʃt ɪz sɔɹd. "baɪ jəɹ liv, mʌðɝ, əl stænd. ðə wɑtʃ ɪz nɑt dʌn."

"Thank you, Mother." He bowed his head, then, as Lan had told him, glanced at the chair and touched his sword. "By your leave, Mother, I will stand. The watch is not done."

ði æmɪɝlɪn sit meɪɾ ən ɪɡzæspɝeɪɾɪd saʊn ən lʊkt ət mɔɪɹeɪn. "hæv jə lɛt læn ət hɪm, dɔɾɝ? ðɪs wɪl bi dɪfəkəlt ɪnʌf wɪθaʊɾ ɪm pɪkɪŋ ʌp wɔɹɾɝ weɪz."

The Amyrlin Seat made an exasperated sound and looked at Moiraine. "Have you let Lan at him, Daughter? This will be difficult enough without him picking up Warder ways."

"læn əz bɪn titʃɪŋ ɔl ðə bɔɪz, mʌðɝ," mɔɪɹeɪn ɹɪplaɪd kɑmli. "hi hæz spɛn ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ taɪm wɪð ðɪs wʌn ðən ði ʌðɝz kəz i kæɹiz ə sɔɹd."

"Lan has been teaching all the boys, Mother," Moiraine replied calmly. "He has spent a little more time with this one than the others because he carries a sword."

ðə bɹaʊn ɛɛs sədaɪ ʃɪftəɾ ɑn əɹ tʃɛɹ. "ðə ɡeɪɾɪn ɑɹ stɪf-nɛkt ən pɹaʊd, mʌðɝ, bʌt jusfəl. aɪ wəd nɑt bi wɪθaʊt toʊmɑs, əz jə wəd nɑt luz ɔlɹɪk. aɪ hæv ivən hɝɾ ə fju ɹɛdz seɪ ðeɪ səmtaɪmz wɪʃ fəɹ ə wɔɹɾɝ. ən ðə ɡɹinz, ʌv kɔɹs. . . ."

The Brown Aes Sedai shifted on her chair. "The Gaidin are stiff-necked and proud, Mother, but useful. I would not be without Tomas, as you would not lose Alric. I have even heard a few Reds say they sometimes wish for a Warder. And the Greens, of course. . . ."

ðə θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ ɔl ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ hɪm, naʊ. "ðɪs sɔɹd," ði æmɪɝlɪn sit sɛd. "ɪɾ əpɪɹz tə bi ə hɛɹən-mɑɹk bleɪd. haʊ dɪɾ i kʌm baɪ ðæt, mɔɪɹeɪn?"

The three Aes Sedai were all ignoring him, now. "This sword," the Amyrlin Seat said. "It appears to be a heron-mark blade. How did he come by that, Moiraine?"

"tæm ælθɹ lɛf ðə tu ɹɪvɝz əz ə bɔɪ, mʌðɝ. hi dʒɔɪn ði ɑɹmi ʌv ɪljən, ən sɝvd ɪn ðə waɪtkloʊk wɔɹ ən ðə læs tu wɔɹz wɪð tiɹ. ɪn taɪm i ɹoʊz tə bi ə bleɪdmæstɝ ən ðə sɛkən kæptən ə ðə kəmpænjənz. æftɝ ði il wɔɹ, tæm ælθɹ ɹɪtɝn tə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz wɪð ə waɪf fɹəm keɪɛmlɪn ən ən ɪnfən bɔɪ. ɪt wʊɾə seɪv mʌtʃ, hæɾ aɪ noʊn ðɪs ɝliɝ, bʌɾ aɪ noʊ ɪt naʊ."

"Tam al'Thor left the Two Rivers as a boy, Mother. He joined the army of Illian, and served in the Whitecloak War and the last two wars with Tear. In time he rose to be a blademaster and the Second Captain of the Companions. After the Aiel War, Tam al'Thor returned to the Two Rivers with a wife from Caemlyn and an infant boy. It would have saved much, had I known this earlier, but I know it now."

ɹænd stɛɹɾ ət mɔɪɹeɪn. hi nu tæm hæd lɛf ðə tu ɹɪvɝz ən kʌm bæk wɪð ən aʊtləndɝ waɪf ən ðə sɔɹd, bʌt ðə ɹɛst. . . . wɛɹ dɪd jə lɝn ɔl ðæt? nɑɾ ɪn ɛmənz fild. ənlɛs nɪneɪiv toʊl jə mɔɹ ðən ʃiz ɛvɝ toʊl mi. ən ɪnfən bɔɪ. ʃi dʌzn seɪ hɪz sʌn. bʌɾ aɪ æm. "əɡɛns tɛɹ." ði æmɪɝlɪn sit fɹaʊn slaɪtli. "wɛl, ðəɹ wɑz bleɪm ɪnʌf ɑn boʊθ saɪdz ɪn ðoʊz wɔɹz. ful mɛn u wəd ɹæðɝ faɪt ðən tɔk. kən jə tɛl ɪf ðə bleɪɾ ɪz əθɛntɪk, vɛɹɪn?"

Rand stared at Moiraine. He knew Tam had left the Two Rivers and come back with an outlander wife and the sword, but the rest. . . . Where did you learn all that? Not in Emond's Field. Unless Nynaeve told you more than she's ever told me. An infant boy. She doesn't say his son. But I am. "Against Tear." The Amyrlin Seat frowned slightly. "Well, there was blame enough on both sides in those wars. Fool men who would rather fight than talk. Can you tell if the blade is authentic, Verin?"

"ðɛɹ ɑɹ tɛsts, mʌðɝ."

"There are tests, Mother."

"ðɛn teɪk ɪɾ ən tɛst ɪt, dɔɾɝ."

"Then take it and test it, Daughter."

ðə θɹi wɪmən wɝ nɑɾ ivən lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm. ɹænd stɛp bæk, ɡɹɪpɪŋ ðə hɪl hɑɹd. "maɪ fɑðɝ ɡeɪv ðɪs sɔɹd tə mi," hi sɛɾ æŋɡɹəli. "noʊbɑdi ɪz teɪkɪŋ ɪt fɹəm mi." ɪt wɑz oʊnli ðən ðəɾ i ɹilaɪz vɛɹɪn hæd nɑt muv fɹəm əɹ tʃɛɹ. hi lʊkt əɾ əm ɪn kənfjuʒən, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹɪkʌvɝ ɪz ikwəlɪbɹiəm.

The three women were not even looking at him. Rand stepped back, gripping the hilt hard. "My father gave this sword to me," he said angrily. "Nobody is taking it from me." It was only then that he realized Verin had not moved from her chair. He looked at them in confusion, trying to recover his equilibrium.

"soʊ," ði æmɪɝlɪn sit sɛd, "ju hæv səm faɪɝ ɪn jə bɪsaɪdz wʌtɛvɝ læn pʊɾ ɪn. ɡʊd. jəl niɾ ɪt."

"So," the Amyrlin Seat said, "you have some fire in you besides whatever Lan put in. Good. You will need it."

"aɪ æm wʌɾ aɪ æm, mʌðɝ," hi mænədʒ smuðli ɪnʌf. "aɪ stæn ɹɛɾi fəɹ wʌt kʌmz."

"I am what I am, Mother," he managed smoothly enough. "I stand ready for what comes."

ði æmɪɝlɪn sit ɡɹɪməst. "læn əz bɪn ət ju. lɪsən tə mi, bɔɪ. ɪn ə fju aʊɝz, ɪŋtʃɹ wɪl liv tə faɪn ðə stoʊlən hɔɹn. jəɹ fɹɛnd, mæt, wɪl ɡoʊ wɪð hɪm. aɪ ɪkspɛk ðət jəɹ ʌðɝ fɹɛnd - pɛɹɪn? - wɪl ɡoʊ, ɔlsoʊ. dʒju wɪʃ tə əkʌmpəni ðɛm?"

The Amyrlin Seat grimaced. "Lan has been at you. Listen to me, boy. In a few hours, Ingtar will leave to find the stolen Horn. Your friend, Mat, will go with him. I expect that your other friend - Perrin? - will go, also. Do you wish to accompany them?"

"mæɾ ən pɛɹɪn ɑɹ ɡoʊɪŋ? waɪ?" bɪleɪɾədli hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd tə æɾ ə ɹɪspɛkfəl, "mʌðɝ."

"Mat and Perrin are going? Why?" Belatedly he remembered to add a respectful, "Mother."

"ju noʊ ʌv ðə dæɡɝ jəɹ fɹɛn kæɹid?" ə twɪst ə hɝ maʊθ ʃoʊd wʌt ʃi θɔɾ ə ðə dæɡɝ. "ðæt wɑz teɪkən, tu. ənlɛs ɪts faʊnd, ðə lɪŋk bɪtwin ɪm ən ðə bleɪd kænɑt bi bɹoʊkən kəmplitli, ən hɪl daɪ. jə kən ɹaɪd wɪð ðɛm, ɪf jə wɑnt. əɹ jə kən steɪ hɪɹ. noʊ daʊt lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ wɪl lɛt jə ɹɪmeɪn əz ə ɡɛst əz lɔŋ əz jə wɪʃ. əl bi livɪŋ tədeɪ, əz wɛl. mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ wɪl əkʌmpəni mi, ən soʊ wɪl ɛɡwin ən nɪneɪiv, soʊ jəl steɪ əloʊn, ɪf jə steɪ. ðə tʃɔɪs ɪz jʊɹz."

"You know of the dagger your friend carried?" A twist of her mouth showed what she thought of the dagger. "That was taken, too. Unless it is found, the link between him and the blade cannot be broken completely, and he will die. You can ride with them, if you want. Or you can stay here. No doubt Lord Agelmar will let you remain as a guest as long as you wish. I will be leaving today, as well. Moiraine Sedai will accompany me, and so will Egwene and Nynaeve, so you will stay alone, if you stay. The choice is yours."

ɹænd stɛɹɾ ət hɝ. ʃiz seɪɪŋ aɪ kən ɡoʊ əz aɪ wɑnt. ɪz ðət wʌt ʃi bɹɔt mi hɪɹ fɔɹ? mæt ɪz daɪɪŋ! hi ɡlænst ət mɔɪɹeɪn, sɪɾɪŋ ɪmpæsɪvli wɪð əɹ hænz foʊldəɾ ɪn əɹ læp. ʃi lʊkt əz ɪf nʌθɪŋ ɪn ðə wɝl kəd kənsɝn əɹ lɛs ðən wɛɹ i wɛnt. wɪtʃ weɪ ɑɹ jə tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʊʃ mi, ɛɛs sədaɪ? bɝn mi, bʌɾ əl ɡoʊ ənʌðɝ. bʌɾ ɪf mæts daɪɪŋ. . . . aɪ kæn əbændən hɪm. laɪt, haʊ ɑɹ wi gɑnə faɪn ðət dæɡɝ?

Rand stared at her. She is saying I can go as I want. Is that what she brought me here for? Mat is dying! He glanced at Moiraine, sitting impassively with her hands folded in her lap. She looked as if nothing in the world could concern her less than where he went. Which way are you trying to push me, Aes Sedai? Burn me, but I'll go another. But if Mat's dying. . . . I can't abandon him. Light, how are we going to find that dagger?

"ju də nɑɾ əv tə meɪk ðə tʃɔɪs naʊ," ði æmɪɝlɪn sɛd. ʃi dɪd nɑt sim tə kɛɹ, iðɝ. "bʌt jəl əv tə tʃuz bɪfɔɹ ɪŋtʃɹ livz."

"You do not have to make the choice now," the Amyrlin said. She did not seem to care, either. "But you will have to choose before Ingtar leaves."

"aɪ wɪl ɹaɪd wɪð ɪŋtʃɹ, mʌðɝ."

"I will ride with Ingtar, Mother."

ði æmɪɝlɪn sit nɑɾəd æbsənli. "naʊ ðət ðəɾ ɪz dɛlt wɪð, wi kən muv ɑn tə ɪmpɔɹɾənt mæɾɝz. aɪ noʊ jə kən tʃænəl, bɔɪ. wʌt dʒju noʊ?"

The Amyrlin Seat nodded absently. "Now that that is dealt with, we can move on to important matters. I know you can channel, boy. What do you know?"

ɹændz maʊθ fɛl oʊpən. kɑɾ ʌp ɪn wɝiɪŋ əbaʊt mæt, hɝ kæʒəwəl wɝdz hɪɾ ɪm laɪk ə swɪŋɪŋ bɑɹn dɔɹ. ɔl ə lænz ædvaɪs ən ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz wɛn spɪnɪŋ. hi stɛɹɾ ət hɝ, lɪkɪŋ ɪz lɪps. ɪt wɑz wʌn θɪŋ tə θɪŋk ʃi nu, ɪntaɪɝli ənʌðɝ tə faɪn aʊt ʃi ɹɪli dɪd. ðə swɛt faɪnəli sipt aʊɾ ɑn ɪz fɔɹhɛd.

Rand's mouth fell open. Caught up in worrying about Mat, her casual words hit him like a swinging barn door. All of Lan's advice and instructions went spinning. He stared at her, licking his lips. It was one thing to think she knew, entirely another to find out she really did. The sweat finally seeped out on his forehead.

ʃi lin fɔɹwɝɾ ɪn əɹ sit, weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɪz ænsɝ, bʌɾ i hæd ðə filɪŋ ʃi wɑntəd tə lin bæk. hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd wʌt læn hæd sɛd. ɪf ʃiz əfɹeɪɾ ə ju. . . . hi wɑntəd tə læf. ɪf ʃi wɑz əfɹeɪɾ ə hɪm.

She leaned forward in her seat, waiting for his answer, but he had the feeling she wanted to lean back. He remembered what Lan had said. If she's afraid of you. . . . He wanted to laugh. If she was afraid of him.

"noʊ, aɪ kænt. aɪ min . . . aɪ dɪdn də ɪɾ ɑn pɝpəs. ɪt dʒʌs hæpənd. aɪ doʊnt wɑnə - tə tʃænəl ðə paʊɝ. aɪ woʊn ɛvɝ də ɪɾ əɡɛn. aɪ swɛɹ ɪt."

"No, I can't. I mean . . . I didn't do it on purpose. It just happened. I don't want to - to channel the Power. I won't ever do it again. I swear it."

"ju doʊnt wɑn tə," ði æmɪɝlɪn sit sɛd. "wɛl, ðæts waɪz ə ju. ən fulɪʃ, tu. səm kən bi tɔt tə tʃænəl; moʊs kænɑt. ə fju, ðoʊ, hæv ðə siɾ ɪn əm ət bɝθ. sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ, ðeɪ wil ðə wʌn paʊɝ wɛðɝ ðeɪ wɑnə əɹ nɑt, əz ʃʊɹli əz ɹoʊ meɪks fɪʃ. jəl kəntɪnju tə tʃænəl, bɔɪ. jə kæn hɛlp ɪt. ən jə hæd bɛɾɝ lɝn tə tʃænəl, lɝn tə kəntʃɹoʊl ɪt, əɹ jəl nɑt laɪv lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə ɡoʊ mæd. ðə wʌn paʊɝ kɪlz ðoʊz u kænɑt kəntʃɹoʊl ɪts floʊ."

"You don't want to," the Amyrlin Seat said. "Well, that's wise of you. And foolish, too. Some can be taught to channel; most cannot. A few, though, have the seed in them at birth. Sooner or later, they wield the One Power whether they want to or not, as surely as roe makes fish. You will continue to channel, boy. You can't help it. And you had better learn to channel, learn to control it, or you will not live long enough to go mad. The One Power kills those who cannot control its flow."

"haʊ æm aɪ səpoʊz tə lɝn?" hi dɪmændəd. mɔɪɹeɪn ən vɛɹɪn dʒʌst sæt ðɛɹ, ənɹʌfəld, wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm. laɪk spaɪɾɝz. "haʊ? mɔɪɹeɪn kleɪmz ʃi kæn titʃ mi ɛniθɪŋ, ən aɪ doʊnt noʊ haʊ tə lɝn, əɹ wʌt. aɪ doʊnt wɑn tə, ɛniweɪ. aɪ wɑnə stɑp. kæn jə ʌndɝstæn ðæt? tə stɑp!"

"How am I supposed to learn?" he demanded. Moiraine and Verin just sat there, unruffled, watching him. Like spiders. "How? Moiraine claims she can't teach me anything, and I don't know how to learn, or what. I don't want to, anyway. I want to stop. Can't you understand that? To stop!"

"aɪ toʊl jə ðə tʃɹuθ, ɹænd," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. ʃi saʊndəɾ əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ hævɪŋ ə plɛzən kɑnvɝseɪʃən. "ðoʊz u kəd titʃ ju, ðə meɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɑɹ θɹi θaʊzən jɪɹz dɛd. noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ lɪvɪŋ kən titʃ jə tə tʌtʃ seɪɾɪn ɛni mɔɹ ðən jə kəd lɝn tə tʌtʃ seɪaɪdɑɹ. ə bɝd kænɑt titʃ ə fɪʃ tə flaɪ, nɔɹ ə fɪʃ titʃ ə bɝd tə swɪm."

"I told you the truth, Rand," Moiraine said. She sounded as if they were having a pleasant conversation. "Those who could teach you, the male Aes Sedai, are three thousand years dead. No Aes Sedai living can teach you to touch saidin any more than you could learn to touch saidar. A bird cannot teach a fish to fly, nor a fish teach a bird to swim."

"aɪ hæv ɔlweɪz θɔt ðət wɑz ə bæd seɪɪŋ," vɛɹɪn sɛd sʌɾənli. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ bɝdz ðət daɪv ən swɪm. ən ɪn ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz ɑɹ fɪʃ ðət flaɪ, wɪð lɔŋ fɪnz ðət stʃɹɛtʃ aʊɾ əz waɪɾ əz jəɹ aʊtstʃɹɛtʃt ɑɹmz, ən biks laɪk sɔɹdz ðət kən pɪɹs. . . ." hɝ wɝdz tʃɹeɪld ɔf ən ʃi bɪkeɪm flʌstɝd. mɔɪɹeɪn ən ði æmɪɝlɪn sit wɝ stɛɹɪŋ əɾ əɹ wɪθaʊɾ ɪkspɹɛʃən.

"I have always thought that was a bad saying," Verin said suddenly. "There are birds that dive and swim. And in the Sea of Storms are fish that fly, with long fins that stretch out as wide as your outstretched arms, and beaks like swords that can pierce. . . ." Her words trailed off and she became flustered. Moiraine and the Amyrlin Seat were staring at her without expression.

ɹænd tʊk ði ɪntɝʌpʃən tə tʃɹaɪ tə ɹɪɡeɪn səm kəntʃɹoʊl ə hɪmsɛlf. əz tæm hæd tɔɾ ɪm lɔŋ əɡoʊ, hi fɔɹmd ə sɪŋɡəl fleɪm ɪn ɪz maɪn ən fɛɾ ɪz fɪɹz ɪndə ɪt, sikɪŋ ɛmptinəs, ðə stɪlnəs ə ðə vɔɪd. ðə fleɪm sim tə ɡɹoʊ əntɪl ɪɾ ɛnvɛləpt ɛvɹiθɪŋ, əntɪl ɪt wɑz tu lɑɹdʒ tə kənteɪn əɹ ɪmædʒən ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. wɪð ðəɾ ɪt wɑz ɡɔn, livɪŋ ɪn ɪts pleɪs ə sɛns ə pis. əɾ ɪts ɛdʒəz, ɪmoʊʃənz stɪl flɪkɝd, fɪɹ ən æŋɡɝ laɪk blæk blɑtʃəz, bʌt ðə vɔɪd hɛld. θɔt skɪmd əkɹɔs ɪts sɝfəs laɪk pɛbəlz əkɹɔs aɪs. ði ɛɛs sədaɪz ətɛnʃən wɑz oʊnli ɔf ɪm fəɹ ə moʊmənt, bʌt wən ðeɪ tɝn bæk ɪz feɪs wɑz kɑm.

Rand took the interruption to try to regain some control of himself. As Tam had taught him long ago, he formed a single flame in his mind and fed his fears into it, seeking emptiness, the stillness of the void. The flame seemed to grow until it enveloped everything, until it was too large to contain or imagine any longer. With that it was gone, leaving in its place a sense of peace. At its edges, emotions still flickered, fear and anger like black blotches, but the void held. Thought skimmed across its surface like pebbles across ice. The Aes Sedai's attention was only off him for a moment, but when they turned back his face was calm.

"waɪ ɑɹ jə tɔkɪŋ tə mi laɪk ðɪs, mʌðɝ?" hi æskt. "ju ʃəd bi dʒɛntəlɪŋ mi."

"Why are you talking to me like this, Mother?" he asked. "You should be gentling me."

ði æmɪɝlɪn sit fɹaʊn ən tɝn tə mɔɪɹeɪn. "dɪd læn titʃ ɪm ðɪs?"

The Amyrlin Seat frowned and turned to Moiraine. "Did Lan teach him this?"

"noʊ, mʌðɝ. hi hæɾ ɪt fɹəm tæm ælθɹ."

"No, Mother. He had it from Tam al'Thor."

"waɪ?" ɹænd dɪmændəɾ əɡɛn.

"Why?" Rand demanded again.

ði æmɪɝlɪn sit lʊkt ɪm stʃɹeɪɾ ɪn ði aɪ ən sɛd, "bɪkɔz jə ɑɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn."

The Amyrlin Seat looked him straight in the eye and said, "Because you are the Dragon Reborn."

ðə vɔɪd ɹɑkt. ðə wɝld ɹɑkt. ɛvɹiθɪŋ sim tə spɪn ɝaʊn hɪm. hi kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾəd ɑn nʌθɪŋ, ən ði ɛmptinəs ɹɪtɝnd, ðə wɝl stɛɾid. "noʊ, mʌðɝ. aɪ kən tʃænəl, ðə laɪt hɛlp mi, bʌɾ aɪm nɑt ɹɑoʊlɪn dɑɹksbeɪn, nɔɹ ɡɛɹ əmɑlɑsən, nɔɹ jʊɹiən stoʊnboʊ. jə kən dʒɛntəl mi, əɹ kɪl mi, əɹ lemi ɡoʊ, bʌɾ əl nɑt bi ə teɪm fɔls dʒɹæɡən ɑn ə tɑɹ vəlɑn liʃ."

The void rocked. The world rocked. Everything seemed to spin around him. He concentrated on nothing, and the emptiness returned, the world steadied. "No, Mother. I can channel, the Light help me, but I am not Raolin Darksbane, nor Guaire Amalasan, nor Yurian Stonebow. You can gentle me, or kill me, or let me go, but I will not be a tame false Dragon on a Tar Valon leash."

hi hɝd vɛɹɪn ɡæsp, ən ði æmɪɝlɪnz aɪz waɪɾənd, ə ɡeɪz əz hɑɹɾ əz blu ɹɑk. ɪt dɪd nɑɾ əfɛk hɪm; ɪt slɪɾ ɔf ðə vɔɪd wɪðɪn.

He heard Verin gasp, and the Amyrlin's eyes widened, a gaze as hard as blue rock. It did not affect him; it slid off the void within.

"wɛɹ dɪd jə hɪɹ ðoʊz neɪmz?" ði æmɪɝlɪn dɪmændəd. "hu toʊl jə tɑɹ vəlɑn pʊlz ðə laɪnz ɑn ɛni fɔls dʒɹæɡən?"

"Where did you hear those names?" the Amyrlin demanded. "Who told you Tar Valon pulls the lines on any false Dragon?"

"ə fɹɛnd, mʌðɝ," hi sɛd. "ə ɡlimən. hɪz neɪm wɑz tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn. hiz dɛd, naʊ." mɔɪɹeɪn meɪɾ ə saʊnd, ən i ɡlænst ət hɝ. ʃi kleɪm tɑm wɑz nɑt dɛd, bʌt ʃi hæd nɛvɝ ɔfɝɾ ɛni pɹuf, ən i kəd nɑt si haʊ ɛni mæn kəd sɝvaɪv ɡɹæplɪŋ hænd-tə-hænd wɪð ə feɪd. ðə θɔt wɑz ɛkstʃɹeɪniəs, ən ɪt feɪɾəd əweɪ. ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli ðə vɔɪɾ ən ðə wʌnnəs naʊ.

"A friend, Mother," he said. "A gleeman. His name was Thom Merrilin. He's dead, now." Moiraine made a sound, and he glanced at her. She claimed Thom was not dead, but she had never offered any proof, and he could not see how any man could survive grappling hand-to-hand with a Fade. The thought was extraneous, and it faded away. There was only the void and the oneness now.

"ju ɑɹ nɑɾ ə fɔls dʒɹæɡən," ði æmɪɝlɪn sɛd fɝmli. "ju ɑɹ ðə tʃɹu dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn."

"You are not a false Dragon," the Amyrlin said firmly. "You are the true Dragon Reborn."

"aɪ æm ə ʃɛpɝd fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, mʌðɝ."

"I am a shepherd from the Two Rivers, Mother."

"dɔɾɝ, tɛl ɪm ðə stɔɹi. ə tʃɹu stɔɹi, bɔɪ. lɪsən wɛl."

"Daughter, tell him the story. A true story, boy. Listen well."

mɔɪɹeɪn bɪɡæn spikɪŋ. ɹænd kɛpt ɪz aɪz ɑn ði æmɪɝlɪnz feɪs, bʌɾ i hɝd.

Moiraine began speaking. Rand kept his eyes on the Amyrlin's face, but he heard.

"nɪɹli twɛnti jɪɹz əɡoʊ ði il kɹɔs ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝld, ðə dʒɹæɡoʊnwɔl, ði oʊnli taɪm ðeɪv ɛvɝ dʌn soʊ. ðeɪ ɹævɪdʒ θɹu kɛɹhin, dɪstʃɹɔɪɾ ɛvɹi ɑɹmi sɛn əɡɛns ðɛm, bɝn ðə sɪɾi ʌv kɛɹhin ɪtsɛlf, ən fɔɾ ɔl ðə weɪ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn. ɪt wɑz wɪntɝ ən snoʊɪŋ, bʌt koʊld əɹ hit min lɪɾəl tə ən il. ðə faɪnəl bæɾəl, ðə læs ðət kaʊntəd, wɑz fɔɾ aʊtsaɪd ðə ʃaɪnɪŋ wɔlz, ɪn ðə ʃædoʊ ʌv dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt. ɪn θɹi deɪz ən θɹi naɪts ə faɪɾɪŋ, ði il wɝ tɝn bæk. əɹ ɹæðɝ ðeɪ tɝn bæk, fəɹ ðeɪ hæd dʌn wʌt ðeɪ keɪm tə du, wɪtʃ wɑz tə kɪl kɪŋ leɪmən ə kɛɹhin, fəɹ ɪz sɪn əɡɛns ðə tʃɹi. ɪts ðən ðət maɪ stɔɹi bɪɡɪnz. ən jʊɹz."

"Nearly twenty years ago the Aiel crossed the Spine of the World, the Dragonwall, the only time they have ever done so. They ravaged through Cairhien, destroyed every army sent against them, burned the city of Cairhien itself, and fought all the way to Tar Valon. It was winter and snowing, but cold or heat mean little to an Aiel. The final battle, the last that counted, was fought outside the Shining Walls, in the shadow of Dragonmount. In three days and three nights of fighting, the Aiel were turned back. Or rather they turned back, for they had done what they came to do, which was to kill King Laman of Cairhien, for his sin against the Tree. It is then that my story begins. And yours."

ðeɪ keɪm oʊvɝ ðə dʒɹæɡoʊnwɔl laɪk ə flʌd. ɔl ðə weɪ tə ðə ʃaɪnɪŋ wɔlz. ɹænd weɪɾəd fəɹ ðə mɛmɹiz tə feɪd, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz tæmz vɔɪs i hɝd, tæm sɪk ən ɹeɪvɪŋ, pʊlɪŋ ʌp sikɹəts fɹəm ɪz pæst. ðə vɔɪs klʌŋ aʊtsaɪd ðə vɔɪd, klæmɝɪŋ tə ɡɛɾ ɪn.

They came over the Dragonwall like a flood. All the way to the Shining Walls. Rand waited for the memories to fade, but it was Tam's voice he heard, Tam sick and raving, pulling up secrets from his past. The voice clung outside the void, clamoring to get in.

"aɪ wɑz wʌn ə ði æksɛptɪd, ðɛn," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, "æz wɑz əɹ mʌðɝ, ði æmɪɝlɪn sit. wi wɝ sun tə bi ɹeɪz tə sɪstɝhʊd, ən ðət naɪt wi stʊɾ ətɛndəns ɑn ðə ðən æmɪɝlɪn. hɝ kipɝ ə ðə kɹɑnəkəlz, ɡɪtɑɹə mɔɹoʊsoʊ, wɑz ðɛɹ. ɛvɹi ʌðɝ fʊl sɪstɝ ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn wɑz aʊt hilɪŋ əz mɛni wundəɾ əz ʃi kəd faɪnd, ivən ðə ɹɛdz. ɪt wɑz dɔn. ðə faɪɝ ɑn ðə hɑɹθ kəd nɑt kip ðə koʊld aʊt. ðə snoʊ hæd faɪnəli stɑpt, ən ɪn ði æmɪɝlɪnz tʃeɪmbɝz ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ wi kəd smɛl ðə smoʊk ʌv aʊtlaɪɪŋ vɪlədʒəz bɝn ɪn ðə faɪɾɪŋ."

"I was one of the Accepted, then," Moiraine said, "as was our Mother, the Amyrlin Seat. We were soon to be raised to sisterhood, and that night we stood attendance on the then Amyrlin. Her Keeper of the Chronicles, Gitara Moroso, was there. Every other full sister in Tar Valon was out Healing as many wounded as she could find, even the Reds. It was dawn. The fire on the hearth could not keep the cold out. The snow had finally stopped, and in the Amyrlin's chambers in the White Tower we could smell the smoke of outlying villages burned in the fighting."

bæɾəlz ɑɹ ɔlweɪz hɑt, ivən ɪn ðə snoʊ. hæd tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ fɹəm ðə stɪŋk ə dɛθ. tæmz dɪlɪɹiəs vɔɪs klɔɾ ət ði ɛmpti kɑm ɪnsaɪd ɹænd. ðə vɔɪd tʃɹɛmbəld ən ʃɹæŋk, stɛɾid, ðən weɪvɝɾ əɡɛn. ði æmɪɝlɪnz aɪz bɔɹɾ ət hɪm. hi fɛl swɛɾ ɑn ɪz feɪs əɡɛn. "ɪt wɑz ɔl ə fivɝ-dʒɹim," hi sɛd. "hi wɑz sɪk." hi ɹeɪzd ɪz vɔɪs. "maɪ neɪm ɪz ɹænd ælθɹ. aɪm ə ʃɛpɝd. maɪ fɑðɝ ɪz tæm ælθɹ, ən maɪ mʌðɝ wɑz - "

Battles are always hot, even in the snow. Had to get away from the stink of death. Tam's delirious voice clawed at the empty calm inside Rand. The void trembled and shrank, steadied, then wavered again. The Amyrlin's eyes bored at him. He felt sweat on his face again. "It was all a fever-dream," he said. "He was sick." He raised his voice. "My name is Rand al'Thor. I am a shepherd. My father is Tam al'Thor, and my mother was - "

mɔɪɹeɪn hæd pɔz fəɹ hɪm, bʌt naʊ hɝ əntʃeɪnʒɪŋ vɔɪs kʌɾ ɪm ɔf, sɑft ən ɹɪlɛnlɪs. "ðə kæɹæəθən saɪkəl, ðə pɹɑfəsiz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən, sɛz ðət ðə dʒɹæɡən wɪl bi ɹibɔɹn ɑn ðə sloʊps ə dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt, wɛɹ i daɪd dʊɹɪŋ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld. ɡɪtɑɹə sədaɪ hæd ðə fɔɹtɛlɪŋ səmtaɪmz. ʃi wɑz oʊld, hɝ hɛɹ əz waɪɾ əz ðə snoʊ aʊtsaɪd, bʌt wən ʃi hæd ðə fɔɹtɛlɪŋ, ɪt wɑz stʃɹɔŋ. ðə mɔɹnɪŋ laɪt θɹu ðə wɪndoʊz wɑz stʃɹɛŋθənɪŋ əz aɪ hændəɾ əɹ ə kʌp ə ti. ði æmɪɝlɪn siɾ æsk mi wʌt nuz ðəɹ wɑz fɹəm ðə fild ə bæɾəl. ən ɡɪtɑɹə sədaɪ stɑɹɾəd ʌp aʊɾ ə hɝ tʃɛɹ, hɝ ɑɹmz ən lɛɡz ɹɪdʒəd, tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ, hɝ feɪs əz ɪf ʃi lʊkt ɪndə ðə pɪɾ ə dum ət ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl, ən ʃi kɹaɪɾ aʊt, 'hi ɪz bɔɹn əɡɛn! aɪ fil hɪm! ðə dʒɹæɡən teɪks ɪz fɝs bɹɛθ ɑn ðə sloʊp ə dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt! hiz kʌmɪŋ! hiz kʌmɪŋ! laɪt hɛlp ʌs! laɪt hɛlp ðə wɝld! hi laɪz ɪn ðə snoʊ ən kɹaɪz laɪk ðə θʌndɝ! hi bɝnz laɪk ðə sʌn!' ən ʃi fɛl fɔɹwɝɾ ɪndə maɪ ɑɹmz, dɛd."

Moiraine had paused for him, but now her unchanging voice cut him off, soft and relentless. "The Karaethon Cycle, the Prophecies of the Dragon, says that the Dragon will be reborn on the slopes of Dragonmount, where he died during the Breaking of the World. Gitara Sedai had the Foretelling sometimes. She was old, her hair as white as the snow outside, but when she had the Foretelling, it was strong. The morning light through the windows was strengthening as I handed her a cup of tea. The Amyrlin Seat asked me what news there was from the field of battle. And Gitara Sedai started up out of her chair, her arms and legs rigid, trembling, her face as if she looked into the Pit of Doom at Shayol Ghul, and she cried out, 'He is born again! I feel him! The Dragon takes his first breath on the slope of Dragonmount! He is coming! He is coming! Light help us! Light help the world! He lies in the snow and cries like the thunder! He burns like the sun!' And she fell forward into my arms, dead."

sloʊp ə ðə maʊntən. hɝɾ ə beɪbi kɹaɪ. ɡeɪv bɝθ ðəɹ əloʊn, bɪfɔɹ ʃi daɪd. tʃaɪl blu wɪð ðə koʊld. ɹænd tʃɹaɪd tə fɔɹs tæmz vɔɪs əweɪ. ðə vɔɪd ɡɹu smɔlɝ. "ə fivɝ-dʒɹim," hi ɡæspt. aɪ kʊdn liv ə tʃaɪld. "aɪ wɑz bɔɹn ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz." ɔlweɪz nu jə wɑntəd tʃɪlʒɹən, kɛɹi. hi pʊld ɪz aɪz əweɪ fɹəm ði æmɪɝlɪnz ɡeɪz. hi tʃɹaɪd tə fɔɹs ðə vɔɪd tə hoʊld. hi nu ðət wɑz nɑt ðə weɪ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz kəlæpsɪŋ ɪn hɪm. jɛs, læs. ɹænd ɪz ə ɡʊd neɪm. "aɪ - æm - ɹænd - ælθɹ!" hɪz lɛɡz tʃɹɛmbəld.

Slope of the mountain. Heard a baby cry. Gave birth there alone, before she died. Child blue with the cold. Rand tried to force Tam's voice away. The void grew smaller. "A fever-dream," he gasped. I couldn't leave a child. "I was born in the Two Rivers." Always knew you wanted children, Kari. He pulled his eyes away from the Amyrlin's gaze. He tried to force the void to hold. He knew that was not the way, but it was collapsing in him. Yes, lass. Rand is a good name. "I - am - Rand - al'Thor!" His legs trembled.

"æn soʊ wi nu ðə dʒɹæɡən wɑz ɹibɔɹn," mɔɪɹeɪn wɛn ɑn. "ði æmɪɝlɪn swɔɹ əs tə sikɹəsi, wi tu, fəɹ ʃi nu nɑɾ ɔl ðə sɪstɝz wəd si ðə ɹibɝθ əz ɪt mʌs bi sin. ʃi sɛɾ əs tə sɝtʃɪŋ. ðəɹ wɝ mɛni fɑðɝləs tʃɪlʒɹən æftɝ ðət bæɾəl. tu mɛni. bʌt wi faʊn ə stɔɹi, ðət wʌn mæn hæd faʊn ən ɪnfən ɑn ðə maʊntən. ðət wɑz ɔl. ə mæn ən ən ɪnfən bɔɪ. soʊ wi sɝtʃt ɑn. fəɹ jɪɹz wi sɝtʃt, faɪndɪŋ ʌðɝ kluz, pɔɹɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə pɹɑfəsiz. 'hi wɪl bi ʌv ði eɪntʃən blʌd, ən ɹeɪz baɪ ði oʊl blʌd.' ðət wɑz wʌn; ðəɹ wɝ ʌðɝz. bʌt ðəɹ ɑɹ mɛni pleɪsəz wɛɹ ði oʊl blʌd, dɪsɛndəd fɹəm ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz, ɹɪmeɪnz stʃɹɔŋ. ðɛn, ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, wɛɹ ði oʊl blʌɾ ə meɪnɛðɝən siθz stɪl laɪk ə ɹɪvɝ ɪn flʌd, ɪn ɛmənz fild, aɪ faʊn θɹi bɔɪz huz neɪm-deɪz wɝ wɪðɪn wiks ə ðə bæɾəl ət dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt. ən wʌn ə ðɛm kən tʃænəl. dɪd jə θɪŋk tʃɹɑləks keɪm æftɝ jə dʒʌs kəz jə ɑɹ tɑvɝən? jə ɑɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn."

"And so we knew the Dragon was Reborn," Moiraine went on. "The Amyrlin swore us to secrecy, we two, for she knew not all the sisters would see the Rebirth as it must be seen. She set us to searching. There were many fatherless children after that battle. Too many. But we found a story, that one man had found an infant on the mountain. That was all. A man and an infant boy. So we searched on. For years we searched, finding other clues, poring over the Prophecies. 'He will be of the ancient blood, and raised by the old blood.' That was one; there were others. But there are many places where the old blood, descended from the Age of Legends, remains strong. Then, in the Two Rivers, where the old blood of Manetheren seethes still like a river in flood, in Emond's Field, I found three boys whose name-days were within weeks of the battle at Dragonmount. And one of them can channel. Did you think Trollocs came after you just because you are ta'veren? You are the Dragon Reborn."

ɹændz niz ɡeɪv weɪ; hi dʒɹɑp tə ə skwɑt, hænz slæpɪŋ ðə ɹʌɡ tə kætʃ hɪmsɛlf fɹəm fɔlɪŋ ɑn ɪz feɪs. ðə vɔɪd wɑz ɡɔn, ðə stɪlnəs ʃæɾɝd. hi ɹeɪzd ɪz hɛd, ən ðeɪ wɝ lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm, ðə θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðɛɹ feɪsəz wɝ sɝin, smuð əz ənɹʌfəl pɑnz, bʌt ðɛɹ aɪz dɪd nɑt blɪŋk. "maɪ fɑðɝ ɪz tæm ælθɹ, ən aɪ wɑz bɔɹn. . . ." ðeɪ stɛɹɾ ət hɪm, ənmoʊvɪŋ. ðəɹ laɪɪŋ. aɪm nɑt . . . wʌt ðeɪ seɪ! səm weɪ, sʌmhaʊ, ðəɹ laɪɪŋ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə juz mi. "aɪ wɪl nɑt bi juz baɪ ju."

Rand's knees gave way; he dropped to a squat, hands slapping the rug to catch himself from falling on his face. The void was gone, the stillness shattered. He raised his head, and they were looking at him, the three Aes Sedai. Their faces were serene, smooth as unruffled ponds, but their eyes did not blink. "My father is Tam al'Thor, and I was born. . . ." They stared at him, unmoving. They're lying. I am not . . . what they say! Some way, somehow, they're lying, trying to use me. "I will not be used by you."

"æn æŋkɝ ɪz nɑt dɪmin baɪ biɪŋ juz tə hoʊld ə boʊt," ði æmɪɝlɪn sɛd. "ju wɝ meɪd fəɹ ə pɝpəs, ɹænd ælθɹ. 'wɛn ðə wɪnz ə tɑɹmən ɡdən skaʊɝ ði ɝθ, hɪl feɪs ðə ʃædoʊ ən bɹɪŋ fɔɹθ laɪɾ əɡɛn ɪn ðə wɝld.' ðə pɹɑfəsiz mʌs bi fʊlfɪld, əɹ ðə dɑɹk wʌn wɪl bɹeɪk fɹi ən ɹimeɪk ðə wɝld ɪn ɪz ɪmədʒ. ðə læs bæɾəl ɪz kʌmɪŋ, ən jə wɝ bɔɹn tə junaɪt mænkaɪn ən lɛɾ əm əɡɛns ðə dɑɹk wʌn."

"An anchor is not demeaned by being used to hold a boat," the Amyrlin said. "You were made for a purpose, Rand al'Thor.
