'When the winds of Tarmon Gai'don scour the earth, he will face the Shadow and bring forth Light again in the world.' The Prophecies must be fulfilled, or the Dark One will break free and remake the world in his image. The Last Battle is coming, and you were born to unite mankind and lead them against the Dark One."

"bælzəmən ɪz dɛd," ɹænd sɛd hɔɹsli, ən ði æmɪɝlɪn snɔɹɾɪd laɪk ə steɪbəlɪhænd.

"Ba'alzamon is dead," Rand said hoarsely, and the Amyrlin snorted like a stablehand.

"ɪf jə bɪliv ðæt, jə ɑɹ əz mʌtʃ ə ful əz ðə dəmɑni. mɛni ðəɹ bɪliv hiz dɛd, əɹ seɪ ðeɪ du, bʌɾ aɪ noʊɾəs ðeɪ stɪl woʊn ɹɪsk neɪmɪŋ hɪm. ðə dɑɹk wʌn laɪvz, ən hiz bɹeɪkɪŋ fɹi. jəl feɪs ðə dɑɹk wʌn. ɪts jəɹ dɛstəni."

"If you believe that, you are as much a fool as the Domani. Many there believe he is dead, or say they do, but I notice they still won't risk naming him. The Dark One lives, and he is breaking free. You will face the Dark One. It is your destiny."

ɪts jəɹ dɛstəni. hi hæd hɝd ðət bɪfɔɹ, ɪn ə dʒɹim ðət hæd meɪbi nɑt bɪn ɪntaɪɝli ə dʒɹim. hi wʌndɝd wʌt ði æmɪɝlɪn wəd seɪ ɪf ʃi nu bælzəmən hæd spoʊkən tə hɪm ɪn dʒɹimz. ðæts dʌn wɪð. bælzəmən ɪz dɛd. aɪ sɔ hɪm daɪ.

It is your destiny. He had heard that before, in a dream that had maybe not been entirely a dream. He wondered what the Amyrlin would say if she knew Ba'alzamon had spoken to him in dreams. That's done with. Ba'alzamon is dead. I saw him die.

sʌɾənli ɪt keɪm tə hɪm ðəɾ i wɑz kɹaʊtʃɪŋ laɪk ə toʊd, hʌɾəlɪŋ ʌndɝ ðɛɹ aɪz. hi tʃɹaɪd tə fɔɹm ðə vɔɪɾ əɡɛn, bʌt vɔɪsəz wɝl θɹu hɪz hɛd, swipɪŋ əweɪ ɛvɹi ɛfɝt. ɪts jəɹ dɛstəni. beɪb laɪɪŋ ɪn ðə snoʊ. jə ɑɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. bælzəmən ɪz dɛd. ɹænd ɪz ə ɡʊd neɪm, kɛɹi. əl nɑt bi juzd! dʒɹɔɪŋ ɑn ɪz oʊn neɪɾɪv stʌbɝnnəs, hi fɔɹs hɪmsɛlf bæk əpɹaɪt. feɪs ɪɾ ɑn jəɹ fit. jə kən kip jəɹ pɹaɪd, ət list. ðə θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑtʃt wɪð noʊ ɪkspɹɛʃən.

Suddenly it came to him that he was crouching like a toad, huddling under their eyes. He tried to form the void again, but voices whirled through his head, sweeping away every effort. It is your destiny. Babe lying in the snow. You are the Dragon Reborn. Ba'alzamon is dead. Rand is a good name, Kari. I will not be used! Drawing on his own native stubbornness, he forced himself back upright. Face it on your feet. You can keep your pride, at least. The three Aes Sedai watched with no expression.

"wʌt. . . ." wɪð ən ɛfɝɾ i stɛɾid ɪz vɔɪs. "wʌɾ ɑɹ jə gɑnə də tə mi?"

"What. . . ." With an effort he steadied his voice. "What are you going to do to me?"

"nʌθɪŋ," ði æmɪɝlɪn sɛd, ən i blɪŋkt. ɪt wɑz nɑt ði ænsɝ i hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd, ðə wʌn i hæd fɪɹd. "ju seɪ jə wɑnə əkʌmpəni jəɹ fɹɛnd wɪð ɪŋtʃɹ, ən jə meɪ. aɪ hæv nɑt mɑɹk jə aʊɾ ɪn ɛni weɪ. səm ə ðə sɪstɝz meɪ noʊ jə ɑɹ tɑvɝən, bʌt noʊ mɔɹ. oʊnli wi θɹi noʊ hu jə tʃɹuli ɑɹ. jəɹ fɹɛn pɛɹɪn wɪl bi bɹɔt tə mi, əz jə wɝ, ən əl vɪzət jəɹ ʌðɝ fɹɛn ɪn ði ɪnfɝmɝi. jə meɪ ɡoʊ əz jə wɪl, wɪθaʊt fɪɹ ðət wɪl sɛt ðə ɹɛd sɪstɝz ɑn ju."

"Nothing," the Amyrlin said, and he blinked. It was not the answer he had expected, the one he had feared. "You say you want to accompany your friend with Ingtar, and you may. I have not marked you out in any way. Some of the sisters may know you are ta'veren, but no more. Only we three know who you truly are. Your friend Perrin will be brought to me, as you were, and I will visit your other friend in the infirmary. You may go as you will, without fear that we will set the Red sisters on you."

hu jə tʃɹuli ɑɹ. æŋɡɝ flɛɹɾ ʌp ɪn hɪm, hɑɾ ən kɝoʊsɪv. hi fɔɹst ɪt tə steɪ ɪnsaɪd, hɪɾən. "waɪ?"

Who you truly are. Anger flared up in him, hot and corrosive. He forced it to stay inside, hidden. "Why?"

"ðə pɹɑfəsiz mʌs bi fʊlfɪld. wi lɛt jə wɔk fɹi, noʊɪŋ wʌt jə ɑɹ, kəz ʌðɝwaɪz ðə wɝld wi noʊ wɪl daɪ, ən ðə dɑɹk wʌn wɪl kʌvɝ ði ɝθ wɪð faɪɝ ən dɛθ. mɑɹk mi, nɑɾ ɔl ɛɛs sədaɪ fil ðə seɪm. ðəɹ ɑɹ səm hɪɹ ɪn fæl dæɹə hu wəd stʃɹaɪk jə daʊn ɪf ðeɪ nu ə tɛnθ ʌv wʌt jə ɑɹ, ən fil noʊ mɔɹ ɹɪmɔɹs ðən fəɹ ɡʌɾɪŋ ə fɪʃ. bʌt ðɛn, ðəɹ ɑɹ mɛn huv noʊ daʊt læft wɪð jə hu wəd də ðə seɪm, ɪf ðeɪ nu. hæv ə kɛɹ, ɹænd ælθɹ, dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn."

"The Prophecies must be fulfilled. We let you walk free, knowing what you are, because otherwise the world we know will die, and the Dark One will cover the earth with fire and death. Mark me, not all Aes Sedai feel the same. There are some here in Fal Dara who would strike you down if they knew a tenth of what you are, and feel no more remorse than for gutting a fish. But then, there are men who've no doubt laughed with you who would do the same, if they knew. Have a care, Rand al'Thor, Dragon Reborn."

hi lʊkt əɾ itʃ ə ðɛm ɪn tɝn. jəɹ pɹɑfəsiz ɑɹ noʊ pɑɹɾ ə mi. ðeɪ ɹɪtɝn ɪz ɡeɪz soʊ kɑmli ɪt wɑz hɑɹd tə bɪliv ðeɪ wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kənvɪns ɪm i wɑz ðə moʊs heɪɾəd, ðə moʊs fɪɹd mæn ɪn ðə hɪstɝi ʌv ðə wɝld. hi hæd ɡɔn ɹaɪt θɹu fɪɹ ən kʌm aʊt ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ɪn səm pleɪs koʊld. æŋɡɝ wɑz ɔl ðət kɛpt ɪm wɔɹm. ðeɪ kəd dʒɛntəl hɪm, əɹ bɝn ɪm tə ə kɹɪsp wɛɹ i stʊd, ən i noʊ lɔŋɡɝ kɛɹd.

He looked at each of them in turn. Your Prophecies are no part of me. They returned his gaze so calmly it was hard to believe they were trying to convince him he was the most hated, the most feared man in the history of the world. He had gone right through fear and come out the other side in some place cold. Anger was all that kept him warm. They could gentle him, or burn him to a crisp where he stood, and he no longer cared.

ə pɑɹɾ ə lænz ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz keɪm bæk tə hɪm. lɛf hæn ɑn ðə hɪlt, hi twɪstəd ðə sɔɹd bɪhaɪn hɪm, kætʃɪŋ ðə skæbɝɾ ɪn ɪz ɹaɪt, ðən baʊd, ɑɹmz stʃɹeɪt. "baɪ jəɹ liv, mʌðɝ, meɪ aɪ dɪpɑɹt ðɪs pleɪs?"

A part of Lan's instructions came back to him. Left hand on the hilt, he twisted the sword behind him, catching the scabbard in his right, then bowed, arms straight. "By your leave, Mother, may I depart this place?"

"aɪ ɡɪv jə liv tə ɡoʊ, maɪ sʌn."

"I give you leave to go, my son."

stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ, hi stʊd ðəɹ ə moʊmən lɔŋɡɝ. "aɪ wɪl nɑt bi juzd," hi toʊl ðɛm. ðəɹ wɑz ə lɔŋ saɪləns əz i tɝn ən lɛft.

Straightening, he stood there a moment longer. "I will not be used," he told them. There was a long silence as he turned and left.

ðə saɪləns stʃɹɛtʃt ɑn ɪn ðə ɹum æftɝ ɹænd lɛft əntɪl ɪt wɑz bɹoʊkən baɪ ə lɔŋ bɹɛθ fɹəm ði æmɪɝlɪn. "aɪ kænɑt meɪk maɪsɛlf laɪk wʌt wi dʒʌs dɪd," ʃi sɛd. "ɪt wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi, bʌt. . . . dɪɾ ɪt wɝk, dɔɾɝz?"

The silence stretched on in the room after Rand left until it was broken by a long breath from the Amyrlin. "I cannot make myself like what we just did," she said. "It was necessary, but. . . . Did it work, Daughters?"

mɔɪɹeɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, dʒʌs ðə slaɪɾəst muvmənt. "aɪ də nɑt noʊ. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi, ən ɪz."

Moiraine shook her head, just the slightest movement. "I do not know. But it was necessary, and is."

"nɛsəsɛɹi," vɛɹɪn əɡɹid. ʃi tʌtʃt əɹ fɔɹhɛd, ðən pɪɹɾ ət ðə dæmpnəs ɑn əɹ fɪŋɡɝz. "hi ɪz stʃɹɔŋ. ən əz stʌbɝn əz jə sɛd, mɔɪɹeɪn. mʌtʃ stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən aɪ ɪkspɛktəd. wi meɪ hæv tə dʒɛntəl ɪm æftɝ ɔl bɪfɔɹ. . . ." hɝ aɪz waɪɾənd. "bʌt wi kænɑt, kən wi? ðə pɹɑfəsiz. ðə laɪt fɝɡɪv əs fəɹ wʌt wəɹ lusɪŋ ɑn ðə wɝld."

"Necessary," Verin agreed. She touched her forehead, then peered at the dampness on her fingers. "He is strong. And as stubborn as you said, Moiraine. Much stronger than I expected. We may have to gentle him after all before. . . ." Her eyes widened. "But we cannot, can we? The Prophecies. The Light forgive us for what we are loosing on the world."

"ðə pɹɑfəsiz," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, nɑɾɪŋ. "æftɝwɝdz, wɪl də əz wi mʌst. əz wi də naʊ."

"The Prophecies," Moiraine said, nodding. "Afterwards, we will do as we must. As we do now."

"æz wi mʌst," ði æmɪɝlɪn sɛd. "jɛs. bʌt wən i lɝnz tə tʃænəl, ðə laɪt hɛlp əs ɔl."

"As we must," the Amyrlin said. "Yes. But when he learns to channel, the Light help us all."

ðə saɪləns ɹɪtɝnd.

The silence returned.

ðəɹ wɑz ə stɔɹm kʌmɪŋ. nɪneɪiv fɛlt ɪt. ə bɪɡ stɔɹm, wɝs ðən ʃi hæɾ ɛvɝ sin. ʃi kəd lɪsən tə ðə wɪnd, ən hɪɹ wʌt ðə wɛðɝ wəd bi. ɔl wɪsdəmz kleɪm tə bi eɪbəl tə də ðæt, ðoʊ mɛni kəd nɑt. nɪneɪiv hæd fɛl mɔɹ kʌmftəɹbəl wɪð ði əbɪləɾi bɪfɔɹ lɝnɪŋ ɪt wɑz ə mænəfɛsteɪʃən ə ðə paʊɝ. ɛni wʊmən u kəd lɪsən tə ðə wɪn kəd tʃænəl, ðoʊ moʊst wɝ pɹɑbli əz ʃi hæd bɪn, ʌnəwɛɹ ʌv wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ, ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪɾ oʊnli ɪn fɪts ən stɑɹts.

There was a storm coming. Nynaeve felt it. A big storm, worse than she had ever seen. She could listen to the wind, and hear what the weather would be. All Wisdoms claimed to be able to do that, though many could not. Nynaeve had felt more comfortable with the ability before learning it was a manifestation of the Power. Any woman who could listen to the wind could channel, though most were probably as she had been, unaware of what she was doing, getting it only in fits and starts.

ðɪs taɪm, ðoʊ, sʌmθɪŋ wɑz ɹɔŋ. aʊtsaɪd, ðə mɔɹnɪŋ sʌn wɑz ə ɡoʊldən bɔl ɪn ə klɪɹ blu skaɪ, ən bɝdz sæŋ ɪn ðə ɡɑɹɾənz, bʌt ðət wɑz nɑɾ ɪt. ðəɹ wʊɾə bɪn nʌθɪŋ tə lɪsnɪŋ tə ðə wɪn ɪf ʃi kəd nɑt fɔɹtɛl ðə wɛðɝ bɪfɔɹ ðə saɪnz wɝ vɪzəbəl. ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɹɔŋ wɪð ðə filɪŋ ðɪs taɪm, sʌmθɪŋ nɑt kwaɪt ðə weɪ ɪt juʒəwəli wɑz. ðə stɔɹm fɛl dɪstənt, tu fɑɹ ɔf fəɹ əɹ tə fil əɾ ɔl. jɛɾ ɪt fɛlt əz ɪf ðə skaɪ əbʌv ʃʊɾə bɪn pɔɹɪŋ daʊn ɹeɪn, ən snoʊ, ən heɪl, ɔl ət ðə seɪm taɪm, wɪð wɪnz haʊlɪŋ tə ʃeɪk ðə stoʊnz ə ðə kip. ən ʃi kəd fil ðə ɡʊd wɛðɝ, tu, læstɪŋ fəɹ deɪz jɛt, bʌt ðət wɑz mjuɾɪd ʌndɝ ði ʌðɝ.

This time, though, something was wrong. Outside, the morning sun was a golden ball in a clear blue sky, and birds sang in the gardens, but that was not it. There would have been nothing to listening to the wind if she could not foretell the weather before the signs were visible. There was something wrong with the feeling this time, something not quite the way it usually was. The storm felt distant, too far off for her to feel at all. Yet it felt as if the sky above should have been pouring down rain, and snow, and hail, all at the same time, with winds howling to shake the stones of the keep. And she could feel the good weather, too, lasting for days yet, but that was muted under the other.

ə blufɪntʃ pɝtʃt ɪn ən æɹoʊslɪt laɪk ə mɑkɝi ʌv əɹ wɛðɝ sɛns, piɹɪŋ ɪndə ðə hɔlweɪ. wən ɪt sɔ hɝ, ɪt vænɪʃt ɪn ə flæʃ ə blu ən waɪt fɛðɝz.

A bluefinch perched in an arrowslit like a mockery of her weather sense, peering into the hallway. When it saw her, it vanished in a flash of blue and white feathers.

ʃi stɛɹɾ ət ðə spɑt wɛɹ ðə bɝd hæd bɪn. ðəɹ ɪz ə stɔɹm, ən ðəɹ ɪzənt. ɪt minz sʌmθɪŋ. bʌt wʌt?

She stared at the spot where the bird had been. There is a storm, and there isn't. It means something. But what?

fɑɹ daʊn ðə hɔl fʊl ʌv wɪmən ən smɔl tʃɪlʒɹən ʃi sɔ ɹænd stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ əweɪ, hɪz ɛskɔɹɾ ʌv wɪmən hæf ɹʌnɪŋ tə kip ʌp. nɪneɪiv nɑɾəd fɝmli. ɪf ðəɹ wɑz ə stɔɹm ðət wɑz nɑɾ ə stɔɹm, hi wəd bi ðə sɛntɝ ʌv ɪt. ɡæðɝɪŋ əɹ skɝts, ʃi hɝiɾ æftɝ hɪm.

Far down the hall full of women and small children she saw Rand striding away, his escort of women half running to keep up. Nynaeve nodded firmly. If there was a storm that was not a storm, he would be the center of it. Gathering her skirts, she hurried after him.

wɪmən wɪð hum ʃi hæd ɡɹoʊn fɹɛnli sɪns kʌmɪŋ tə fæl dæɹə tʃɹaɪd tə spik tə hɝ; ðeɪ nu ɹænd hæd kʌm wɪð əɹ ən ðət ðeɪ wɝ boʊθ fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, ən ðeɪ wɑntəd tə noʊ waɪ ði æmɪɝlɪn hæd sʌmən hɪm. ði æmɪɝlɪn sit! aɪs ɪn ðə pɪɾ ə hɝ bɛli, ʃi bɹoʊk ɪndə ə ɹʌn, bʌt bɪfɔɹ ʃi lɛf ðə wɪmənz əpɑɹtməns, ʃi hæd lɔst ɪm ɝaʊn tu mɛni kɔɹnɝz ən bɪɑn tu mɛni pipəl.

Women with whom she had grown friendly since coming to Fal Dara tried to speak to her; they knew Rand had come with her and that they were both from the Two Rivers, and they wanted to know why the Amyrlin had summoned him. The Amyrlin Seat! Ice in the pit of her belly, she broke into a run, but before she left the women's apartments, she had lost him around too many corners and beyond too many people.

"wɪtʃ weɪ dɪɾ i ɡoʊ?" ʃi æsk nɪʃʊɹə. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid tə seɪ hu. ʃi hɝd ɹændz neɪm ɪn ðə kɑnvɝseɪʃən ə ði ʌðɝ wɪmən klʌstɝɾ ɝaʊn ði ɑɹtʃt dɔɹz.

"Which way did he go?" she asked Nisura. There was no need to say who. She heard Rand's name in the conversation of the other women clustered around the arched doors.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ, nɪneɪiv. hi keɪm aʊɾ əz fæst əz ɪf i hæd hɑɹtsbeɪn hɪmsɛlf əɾ ɪz hilz. əz wɛl i maɪt, kʌmɪŋ hɪɹ wɪð ə sɔɹɾ əɾ ɪz bɛlt. ðə dɑɹk wʌn ʃəd bi ðə list ə hɪz wɝiz æftɝ ðæt. wʌɾ ɪz ðə wɝl kʌmɪŋ tə? ən ɪm pɹizɛntəd tə ði æmɪɝlɪn ɪn əɹ tʃeɪmbɝz, noʊ lɛs. tɛl mi, nɪneɪiv, ɪz i ɹɪli ə pɹɪns ɪn jəɹ lænd?" ði ʌðɝ wɪmən stɑp tɔkɪŋ ən lin kloʊsɝ tə lɪsən.

"I don't know, Nynaeve. He came out as fast as if he had Heartsbane himself at his heels. As well he might, coming here with a sword at his belt. The Dark One should be the least of his worries after that. What is the world coming to? And him presented to the Amyrlin in her chambers, no less. Tell me, Nynaeve, is he really a prince in your land?" The other women stopped talking and leaned closer to listen.

nɪneɪiv wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ wʌt ʃi ænsɝd. sʌmθɪŋ ðət meɪɾ əm lɛɾ əɹ ɡoʊ ɑn. ʃi hɝiɾ əweɪ fɹəm ðə wɪmənz əpɑɹtməns, hɛd swɪvəlɪŋ əɾ ɛvɹi kɹɔsɪŋ kɔɹəɾɝ tə lʊk fəɹ hɪm, fɪsts klɛntʃt. laɪt, wʌɾ əv ðeɪ dʌn tə hɪm? aɪ ʃʊɾə ɡɑɾən ɪm əweɪ fɹəm mɔɪɹeɪn sʌmhaʊ, ðə laɪt blaɪn hɝ. ɪm ɪz wɪzdəm.

Nynaeve was not sure what she answered. Something that made them let her go on. She hurried away from the women's apartments, head swiveling at every crossing corridor to look for him, fists clenched. Light, what have they done to him? I should have gotten him away from Moiraine somehow, the Light blind her. I'm his Wisdom.

ɑɹ ju, ə smɔl vɔɪs tɔntɪd. juv əbændən ɛmənz fil tə fɛn fəɹ ɪtsɛlf. kən jə stɪl kɔl jɝsɛlf ðɛɹ wɪzdəm?

Are you, a small voice taunted. You've abandoned Emond's Field to fend for itself. Can you still call yourself their Wisdom?

aɪ dɪd nɑɾ əbændən ðɛm, ʃi toʊl hɝsɛlf fɪɹsli. aɪ bɹɔt mævɹə mɔlən ʌp fɹəm dɛvən ɹaɪd tə lʊk æftɝ mæɾɝz tɪl aɪ ɡɛt bæk. ʃi kən dil wɛl ɪnʌf wɪð ðə meɪɝ ən ðə vɪlədʒ kaʊnsəl, ən ʃi ɡɛts ɑn wɛl wɪð ðə wɪmənz sɝkəl.

I did not abandon them, she told herself fiercely. I brought Mavra Mallen up from Deven Ride to look after matters till I get back. She can deal well enough with the Mayor and the Village Council, and she gets on well with the Women's Circle.

mævɹə wɪl əv tə ɡɛt bæk tə hɝ oʊn vɪlədʒ. noʊ vɪlədʒ kən də wɪθaʊɾ ɪts wɪzdəm fəɹ lɔŋ. nɪneɪiv kɹɪnʒd ɪnsaɪd. ʃi hæd bɪn ɡɔn mʌnθs fɹəm ɛmənz fild.

Mavra will have to get back to her own village. No village can do without its Wisdom for long. Nynaeve cringed inside. She had been gone months from Emond's Field.

"aɪ æm ðə wɪzdəm ʌv ɛmənz fild!" ʃi sɛɾ əlaʊd.

"I am the Wisdom of Emond's Field!" she said aloud.

ə lɪvɹid sɝvən kæɹiɪŋ ə boʊlt ə klɔθ blɪŋkt ət hɝ, ðən baʊd loʊ bɪfɔɹ skɝiɪŋ ɔf. baɪ hɪz feɪs i wɑz iɡɝ tə bi ɛniwɛɹ ɛls.

A liveried servant carrying a bolt of cloth blinked at her, then bowed low before scurrying off. By his face he was eager to be anywhere else.

blʌʃɪŋ, nɪneɪiv lʊkt ɝaʊn tə si ɪf ɛniwʌn hæd noʊɾəst. ðəɹ wɝ oʊnli ə fju mɛn ɪn ðə hɔl, ɪnɡɹoʊst ɪn ðɛɹ oʊn kɑnvɝseɪʃənz, ən səm wɪmən ɪn blæk-ænd-ɡoʊld ɡoʊɪŋ əbaʊt ðɛɹ bɪznəs, ɡɪvɪŋ əɹ ə baʊ əɹ kɝtsi əz ʃi pæst. ʃi hæd hæd ðəɾ ɑɹɡjəmənt wɪð hɝsɛlf ə hʌnʒɹəd taɪmz bɪfɔɹ, bʌt ðɪs wɑz ðə fɝs taɪm ɪt hæd kʌm tə tɔkɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf aʊt laʊd. ʃi mʌɾɝd ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ, ðən pɹɛst əɹ lɪps fɝmli təɡɛðɝ wən ʃi ɹilaɪzd wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ.

Blushing, Nynaeve looked around to see if anyone had noticed. There were only a few men in the hall, engrossed in their own conversations, and some women in black-and-gold going about their business, giving her a bow or curtsy as she passed. She had had that argument with herself a hundred times before, but this was the first time it had come to talking to herself out loud. She muttered under her breath, then pressed her lips firmly together when she realized what she was doing.

ʃi wɑz faɪnəli bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə ɹilaɪz əɹ sɝtʃ wɑz fjuɾəl wən ʃi keɪm ɑn læn, hɪz bæk tə hɝ, lʊkɪŋ daʊn ɑn ði aʊɾɝ kɔɹtʃjɑɹd θɹu ən æɹoʊslɪt. ðə nɔɪz fɹəm ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd wɑz ɔl hɔɹsəz ən mɛn, neɪɪŋ ən ʃaʊɾɪŋ. soʊ ɪntɛnt wɑz læn ðəɾ i dɪd nɑt, fəɹ wʌns, sim tə hɪɹ hɝ. ʃi heɪɾəd ðə fæk ðət ʃi kəd nɛvɝ snik ʌp ɑn hɪm, haʊɛvɝ sɔfli ʃi stɛpt. ʃi hæd bɪn əkaʊntəd ɡʊɾ ət wʊdskɹæf bæk ɪn ɛmənz fild, ðoʊ ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə skɪl ɪn wɪtʃ mɛni wɪmən tʊk ɛni ɪntʃɹəst.

She was finally beginning to realize her search was futile when she came on Lan, his back to her, looking down on the outer courtyard through an arrowslit. The noise from the courtyard was all horses and men, neighing and shouting. So intent was Lan that he did not, for once, seem to hear her. She hated the fact that she could never sneak up on him, however softly she stepped. She had been accounted good at woodscraft back in Emond's Field, though it was not a skill in which many women took any interest.

ʃi stɑpt ɪn əɹ tʃɹæks, pɹɛsɪŋ əɹ hænz tə hɝ stʌmək tə kwaɪəɾ ə flʌɾɝ. aɪ ɔt tə doʊs maɪsɛlf wɪð ɹænəl ən ʃipstɔŋ ɹut, ʃi θɔt saʊɝli. ɪt wɑz ðə mɪkstʃɝ ʃi ɡeɪv ɛniwʌn u moʊpt əbaʊɾ ən kleɪm ðeɪ wɝ sɪk, əɹ bɪheɪv laɪk ə ɡus. ɹænəl ən ʃipstɔŋ ɹut wəd pɝk jə ʌp ə lɪɾəl, ən dɪd noʊ hɑɹm, bʌt meɪnli ɪt teɪstəd hɔɹəbəl, ən ðə teɪs læstəɾ ɔl deɪ. ɪt wɑz ə pɝfəkt kjʊɹ fəɹ æktɪŋ ðə ful.

She stopped in her tracks, pressing her hands to her stomach to quiet a flutter. I ought to dose myself with rannel and sheepstongue root, she thought sourly. It was the mixture she gave anyone who moped about and claimed they were sick, or behaved like a goose. Rannel and sheepstongue root would perk you up a little, and did no harm, but mainly it tasted horrible, and the taste lasted all day. It was a perfect cure for acting the fool.

seɪf fɹəm ɪz aɪz, ʃi stʌɾid ðə lɛŋθ ə hɪm, linɪŋ əɡɛns ðə stoʊn ən fɪŋɡɝɪŋ ɪz tʃɪn əz i stʌɾid wʌt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn bɪloʊ. hiz tu tɔl, fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ, ən oʊld ɪnʌf tə bi maɪ fɑðɝ, fəɹ ənʌðɝ. ə mæn wɪð ə feɪs laɪk ðət wəɾ əv tə bi kɹuəl. noʊ, hiz nɑt ðæt. nɛvɝ ðæt. ən i wɑz ə kɪŋ. hɪz lænd wɑz dɪstʃɹɔɪd waɪl i wɑz ə tʃaɪld, ən i wəd nɑt kleɪm ə kɹaʊn, bʌɾ i wɑz ə kɪŋ, fəɹ ðæt. wʌt wəɾ ə kɪŋ wɑnt wɪð ə vɪlədʒ wʊmən? hiz ə wɔɹɾɝ, tu. bɑndəd tə mɔɪɹeɪn. ʃiz ɪz lɔɪəlti tə dɛθ, ən taɪz kloʊsɝ ðən ɛni lʌvɝ, ən ʃiz hɪm. ʃiz ɛvɹiθɪŋ aɪ wɑnt, ðə laɪt bɝn hɝ!

Safe from his eyes, she studied the length of him, leaning against the stone and fingering his chin as he studied what was going on below. He's too tall, for one thing, and old enough to be my father, for another. A man with a face like that would have to be cruel. No, he's not that. Never that. And he was a king. His land was destroyed while he was a child, and he would not claim a crown, but he was a king, for that. What would a king want with a village woman? He's a Warder, too. Bonded to Moiraine. She has his loyalty to death, and ties closer than any lover, and she has him. She has everything I want, the Light burn her!

hi tɝn fɹəm ði æɹoʊslɪt, ən ʃi wɝl tə ɡoʊ.

He turned from the arrowslit, and she whirled to go.

"nɪneɪiv." hɪz vɔɪs kɑɾ ən hɛld əɹ laɪk ə nus. "aɪ wɑntəd tə spik tə jə əloʊn. jə ɔlweɪz sim tə bi ɪn ðə wɪmənz əpɑɹtməns, əɹ ɪn kʌmpəni."

"Nynaeve." His voice caught and held her like a noose. "I wanted to speak to you alone. You always seem to be in the women's apartments, or in company."

ɪt tʊk ən ɛfɝt tə feɪs hɪm, bʌt ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ əɹ fitʃɝz wɝ kɑm wən ʃi lʊkt ʌp ət hɪm. "aɪm lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ɹænd." ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə ədmɪt tə əvɔɪɾɪŋ hɪm. "wi sɛɾ ɔl wi nid tə seɪ lɔŋ əɡoʊ, jə ən aɪ. aɪ ʃeɪmd maɪsɛlf - wɪtʃ əl nɑt də əɡɛn - ən jə toʊl mi tə ɡoʊ əweɪ."

It took an effort to face him, but she was sure her features were calm when she looked up at him. "I'm looking for Rand." She was not about to admit to avoiding him. "We said all we need to say long ago, you and I. I shamed myself - which I will not do again - and you told me to go away."

"aɪ nɛvɝ sɛd - " hi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. "aɪ toʊl jə aɪ hæd nʌθɪŋ tə ɔfɝ fəɹ bɹɪɾɪpɹaɪs bʌt wɪɾoʊz kloʊðz. nɑɾ ə ɡɪft ɛni mæn kəd ɡɪv ə wʊmən. nɑɾ ə mæn u kən kɔl hɪmsɛlf ə mæn."

"I never said - " He took a deep breath. "I told you I had nothing to offer for brideprice but widow's clothes. Not a gift any man could give a woman. Not a man who can call himself a man."

"aɪ ʌndɝstænd," ʃi sɛd kuli. "ɪn ɛni keɪs, ə kɪŋ dʌz nɑt ɡɪv ɡɪfs tə vɪlədʒ wɪmən. ən ðɪs vɪlədʒ wʊmən wəd nɑt teɪk ðɛm. hæv jə sin ɹænd? aɪ nid tə tɔk tə hɪm. hi wɑz tə si ði æmɪɝlɪn. dʒju noʊ wʌt ʃi wɑntəd wɪð hɪm?"

"I understand," she said coolly. "In any case, a king does not give gifts to village women. And this village woman would not take them. Have you seen Rand? I need to talk to him. He was to see the Amyrlin. Do you know what she wanted with him?"

hɪz aɪz bleɪz laɪk blu aɪs ɪn ðə sʌn. ʃi stɪfən əɹ lɛɡz tə kip fɹəm stɛpɪŋ bæk, ən mɛɾ ɪm ɡlɛɹ fəɹ ɡlɛɹ.

His eyes blazed like blue ice in the sun. She stiffened her legs to keep from stepping back, and met him glare for glare.

"ðə dɑɹk wʌn teɪk ɹænd ælθɹ ən ði æmɪɝlɪn sit boʊθ," hi ɡɹeɪɾɪd, pɹɛsɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ ɪndə hɝ hænd. "aɪ wɪl meɪk jə ə ɡɪft ən jəl teɪk ɪɾ ɪf aɪ hæv tə tʃeɪn ɪɾ ɝaʊn jəɹ nɛk."

"The Dark One take Rand al'Thor and the Amyrlin Seat both," he grated, pressing something into her hand. "I will make you a gift and you will take it if I have to chain it around your neck."

ʃi pʊld əɹ aɪz əweɪ fɹəm hɪz. hi hæɾ ə stɛɹ laɪk ə blu-aɪd hɔk wən i wɑz æŋɡɹi. ɪn əɹ hænd wɑz ə sɪɡnɪt ɹɪŋ, hɛvi ɡoʊld ən wɔɹn wɪð eɪdʒ, ɔlmoʊs lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf fəɹ boʊθ əɹ θʌmz tə fɪt θɹu. ɑn ɪt, ə kɹeɪn flu əbʌv ə læns ən kɹaʊn, ɔl kɛɹfəli ɹɔɾ ɪn dɪteɪl. hɝ bɹɛθ kɑt. ðə ɹɪŋ ə mɔlkɪɹi kɪŋz. fɝɡɛɾɪŋ tə ɡlɛɹ, ʃi lɪftəɾ əɹ feɪs. "aɪ kænɑt teɪk ðɪs, læn."

She pulled her eyes away from his. He had a stare like a blue-eyed hawk when he was angry. In her hand was a signet ring, heavy gold and worn with age, almost large enough for both her thumbs to fit through. On it, a crane flew above a lance and crown, all carefully wrought in detail. Her breath caught. The ring of Malkieri kings. Forgetting to glare, she lifted her face. "I cannot take this, Lan."

hi ʃɹʌɡd ɪn ən ɔfhænd weɪ. "ɪɾ ɪz nʌθɪŋ. oʊld, ən jusləs, naʊ. bʌt ðəɹ ɑɹ ðoʊz u wəd noʊ ɪt wən ðeɪ sɔ ɪt. ʃoʊ ðæt, ən jəl əv ɡɛstʃɹaɪt, ən hɛlp ɪf jə niɾ ɪt, fɹəm ɛni lɔɹɾ ɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz. ʃoʊ ɪt tə ə wɔɹɾɝ, ən hɪl ɡɪv eɪd, əɹ kæɹi ə mɛsədʒ tə mi. sɛn ɪt tə mi, əɹ ə mɛsədʒ mɑɹkt wɪð ɪt, ən əl kʌm tə ju, wɪθaʊt dɪleɪ ən wɪθaʊt feɪl. ðɪs aɪ swɛɹ."

He shrugged in an offhand way. "It is nothing. Old, and useless, now. But there are those who would know it when they saw it. Show that, and you will have guestright, and help if you need it, from any lord in the Borderlands. Show it to a Warder, and he will give aid, or carry a message to me. Send it to me, or a message marked with it, and I will come to you, without delay and without fail. This I swear."

hɝ vɪʒən blɝɾ ət ði ɛdʒəz. ɪf aɪ kɹaɪ naʊ, əl kɪl maɪsɛlf. "aɪ kænt. . . . aɪ də nɑt wɑn ə ɡɪft fɹəm ju, ælən mænʒɹɑɡɔɹən. hɪɹ, teɪk ɪt."

Her vision blurred at the edges. If I cry now, I will kill myself. "I can't. . . . I do not want a gift from you, al'Lan Mandragoran. Here, take it."

hi fɛndɪɾ ɔf əɹ ətɛmps tə ɡɪv ðə ɹɪŋ bæk tə hɪm. hɪz hæn ɛnvɛləp hɝz, dʒɛntəl bʌt fɝm əz ə ʃækəl. "ðɛn teɪk ɪt fəɹ maɪ seɪk, əz ə feɪvɝ tə mi. əɹ θɹoʊ ɪɾ əweɪ, ɪf ɪt dɪsplisɪz ju. aɪv noʊ bɛɾɝ jus fəɹ ɪt." hi bɹʌʃt əɹ tʃik wɪð ə fɪŋɡɝ, ən ʃi ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt. "aɪ mʌst ɡoʊ naʊ, nɪneɪiv mæʃiɑɹə. ði æmɪɝlɪn wɪʃɪz tə liv bɪfɔɹ mɪddeɪ, ən ðəɹ ɪz mʌtʃ jɛt tə bi dʌn. pɝhæps wɪl əv taɪm tə tɔk ɑn ðə dʒɝni tə tɑɹ vəlɑn." hi tɝn ən wɑz ɡɔn, stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ daʊn ðə hɔl.

He fended off her attempts to give the ring back to him. His hand enveloped hers, gentle but firm as a shackle. "Then take it for my sake, as a favor to me. Or throw it away, if it displeases you. I've no better use for it." He brushed her cheek with a finger, and she gave a start. "I must go now, Nynaeve mashiara. The Amyrlin wishes to leave before midday, and there is much yet to be done. Perhaps we will have time to talk on the journey to Tar Valon." He turned and was gone, striding down the hall.

nɪneɪiv tʌtʃt əɹ tʃik. ʃi kəd stɪl fil wɛɹ i hæd tʌtʃt hɝ. mæʃiɑɹə. bɪlʌvd ə hɑɹɾ ən soʊl, ɪt mɛnt, bʌɾ ə lʌv lɔst, tu. lɔs bɪɑn ɹɪɡeɪnɪŋ. ful wʊmən! stɑp æktɪŋ laɪk ə ɡɝl wɪð əɹ hɛɹ stɪl nɑt bɹeɪɾɪd. ɪts noʊ jus lɛɾɪŋ ɪm meɪk jə fil. . . .

Nynaeve touched her cheek. She could still feel where he had touched her. Mashiara. Beloved of heart and soul, it meant, but a love lost, too. Lost beyond regaining. Fool woman! Stop acting like a girl with her hair still not braided. It's no use letting him make you feel. . . .

klʌtʃɪŋ ðə ɹɪŋ taɪtli, ʃi tɝn ɝaʊnd, ən dʒʌmpt wən ʃi faʊn hɝsɛlf feɪs-tə-feɪs wɪð mɔɪɹeɪn. "haʊ lɔŋ əv jə bɪn ðɛɹ?" ʃi dɪmændəd.

Clutching the ring tightly, she turned around, and jumped when she found herself face-to-face with Moiraine. "How long have you been there?" she demanded.

"nɑt lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə hɪɹ ɛniθɪŋ aɪ ʃəd nɑt hæv," ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹɪplaɪd smuðli. "wi wɪl bi livɪŋ sun. aɪ hɝd ðæt. jə mʌst si tə jəɹ pækɪŋ."

"Not long enough to hear anything I should not have," the Aes Sedai replied smoothly. "We will be leaving soon. I heard that. You must see to your packing."

livɪŋ. ɪt hæd nɑt pɛnətʃɹeɪɾəd wən læn sɛɾ ɪt. "aɪ wɪl əv tə seɪ ɡʊdbaɪ tə ðə bɔɪz," ʃi mʌɾɝd, ðən ɡeɪv mɔɪɹeɪn ə ʃɑɹp lʊk. "wʌɾ əv jə dʌn tə ɹænd? hi wɑz teɪkən tə ði æmɪɝlɪn. waɪ? dɪd jə tɛl əɹ əbaʊt - əbaʊt . . . ?" ʃi kəd nɑt seɪ ɪt. hi wɑz fɹəm əɹ oʊn vɪlədʒ, ən ʃi wɑz dʒʌst ɪnʌf oʊldɝ ðən i tə hæv lʊkt æftɝ ɪm ə taɪm əɹ tu wən i wɑz lɪɾəl, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑɾ ivən θɪŋk əbaʊt wʌɾ i hæd bɪkʌm wɪθaʊɾ əɹ stʌmək twɪstɪŋ.

Leaving. It had not penetrated when Lan said it. "I will have to say goodbye to the boys," she muttered, then gave Moiraine a sharp look. "What have you done to Rand? He was taken to the Amyrlin. Why? Did you tell her about - about . . . ?" She could not say it. He was from her own village, and she was just enough older than he to have looked after him a time or two when he was little, but she could not even think about what he had become without her stomach twisting.

"ði æmɪɝlɪn wɪl bi siɪŋ ɔl θɹi, nɪneɪiv. tɑvɝən ɑɹ nɑt soʊ kɑmən ðət ʃi wəd mɪs ðə tʃæns tə si θɹi təɡɛðɝ ɪn wʌn pleɪs. pɝhæps ʃɪl ɡɪv əm ə fju wɝdz ʌv ɛnkɝɪdʒmənt, sɪns ðeɪ ɑɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ wɪð ɪŋtʃɹ tə hʌn ðoʊz u stoʊl ðə hɔɹn. ðəl bi livɪŋ əbaʊt ðə taɪm wi du, soʊ jə hæd bɛɾɝ hɝi wɪð ɛni fɛɹwɛlz."

"The Amyrlin will be seeing all three, Nynaeve. Ta'veren are not so common that she would miss the chance to see three together in one place. Perhaps she will give them a few words of encouragement, since they are riding with Ingtar to hunt those who stole the Horn. They will be leaving about the time we do, so you had better hurry with any farewells."

nɪneɪiv dæʃt tə ðə nɪɹəst æɹoʊslɪɾ ən pɪɹd daʊn ət ði aʊɾɝ kɔɹtʃjɑɹd. hɔɹsəz wɝ ɛvɹiwɛɹ, pæk ænəməlz ən sæɾəl hɔɹsəz, ən mɛn hɝiɪŋ əbaʊt ðɛm, kɔlɪŋ tə itʃ ʌðɝ. ði oʊnli klɪɹ speɪs wɑz wɛɹ ði æmɪɝlɪnz pɑlɑnkwɪn stʊd, ɪts pɛɹd hɔɹsəz weɪɾɪŋ peɪʃənli wɪθaʊɾ ɛni ətɛndəns. səm ə ðə wɔɹɾɝz wɝ aʊt ðɛɹ, lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ðɛɹ maʊns, ən ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd, ɪŋtʃɹ stʊd wɪð ə nɑɾ ə ʃaɪnɝənz ɝaʊn ɪm ɪn ɑɹmɝ. səmtaɪmz ə wɔɹɾɝ əɹ wʌn ʌv ɪŋtʃɹz mɛn kɹɔs ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz tə ɪkstʃeɪnʒ ə wɝd.

Nynaeve dashed to the nearest arrowslit and peered down at the outer courtyard. Horses were everywhere, pack animals and saddle horses, and men hurrying about them, calling to each other. The only clear space was where the Amyrlin's palanquin stood, its paired horses waiting patiently without any attendants. Some of the Warders were out there, looking over their mounts, and on the other side of the courtyard, Ingtar stood with a knot of Shienarans around him in armor. Sometimes a Warder or one of Ingtar's men crossed the paving stones to exchange a word.

"aɪ ʃʊɾə ɡɑɾən ðə bɔɪz əweɪ fɹəm ju," ʃi sɛd, stɪl lʊkɪŋ aʊt. ɛɡwin, tu, ɪf aɪ kəd də ɪt wɪθaʊt kɪlɪŋ hɝ. laɪt, waɪ dɪd ʃi hæv tə bi bɔɹn wɪð ðɪs kɝst əbɪləɾi? "aɪ ʃʊɾə teɪkən əm bæk hoʊm."

"I should have gotten the boys away from you," she said, still looking out. Egwene, too, if I could do it without killing her. Light, why did she have to be born with this cursed ability? "I should have taken them back home."

"ðeɪ ɑɹ mɔɹ ðən oʊld ɪnʌf tə bi ɔf eɪpɹən stʃɹɪŋz," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd dʒɹaɪli. "æn jə noʊ vɛɹi wɛl waɪ jə kəd nɛvɝ də ðæt. fəɹ wʌn ə ðɛm, ət list. bɪsaɪdz, ɪt wəd min livɪŋ ɛɡwin tə ɡoʊ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn əloʊn. əɹ əv jə dɪsaɪɾɪd tə fɔɹɡoʊ tɑɹ vəlɑn jɝsɛlf? ɪf jəɹ oʊn jus ə ðə paʊɝ ɪz nɑt skuld, jəl nɛvɝ bi eɪbəl tə juz ɪɾ əɡɛns mi."

"They are more than old enough to be off apron strings," Moiraine said dryly. "And you know very well why you could never do that. For one of them, at least. Besides, it would mean leaving Egwene to go to Tar Valon alone. Or have you decided to forgo Tar Valon yourself? If your own use of the Power is not schooled, you will never be able to use it against me."

nɪneɪiv spʌn tə feɪs ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, hɝ dʒɔ dʒɹɑpɪŋ. ʃi kəd nɑt hɛlp ɪt. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt jə ɑɹ tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt."

Nynaeve spun to face the Aes Sedai, her jaw dropping. She could not help it. "I don't know what you are talking about."

"dɪd jə θɪŋk aɪ dɪd nɑt noʊ, tʃaɪld? wɛl, əz jə wɪʃ ɪt. aɪ teɪk ɪt ðət jə ɑɹ kʌmɪŋ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn? jɛs, aɪ θɔt soʊ."

"Did you think I did not know, child? Well, as you wish it. I take it that you are coming to Tar Valon? Yes, I thought so."

nɪneɪiv wɑntəd tə hɪt hɝ, tə nɑk əweɪ ðə bɹif smaɪl ðət flæʃt əkɹɔs ði ɛɛs sədaɪz feɪs. ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd nɑt bɪn eɪbəl tə wil paʊɝ oʊpənli sɪns ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ, mʌtʃ lɛs ðə wʌn paʊɝ, bʌt ðeɪ plɑɾəd ən mənɪpjəleɪɾɪd, pʊl stʃɹɪŋz laɪk pʌptmæstɝz, juz θɹoʊnz ən neɪʃənz laɪk stoʊnz ɑn ə stoʊnz bɔɹd. ʃi wɑns tə juz mi, tu, sʌmhaʊ. ɪf ə kɪŋ əɹ ə kwin, waɪ nɑɾ ə wɪzdəm? dʒʌs ðə weɪ ʃiz juzɪŋ ɹænd. ɪm noʊ tʃaɪld, ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Nynaeve wanted to hit her, to knock away the brief smile that flashed across the Aes Sedai's face. Aes Sedai had not been able to wield power openly since the Breaking, much less the One Power, but they plotted and manipulated, pulled strings like puppetmasters, used thrones and nations like stones on a stones board. She wants to use me, too, somehow. If a king or a queen, why not a Wisdom? Just the way she's using Rand. I'm no child, Aes Sedai.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ wɪð ɹænd, naʊ? hæv jə nɑt juzd ɪm ɪnʌf? aɪ doʊnt noʊ waɪ juv nɑt hæɾ ɪm dʒɛntəld, naʊ ði æmɪɝlɪnz hɪɹ wɪð ɔl ðoʊz ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌt jə mʌst əv ə ɹizən. ɪt mʌs bi səm plɑt jəɹ hætʃɪŋ. ɪf ði æmɪɝlɪn nu wʌt jə wɝ ʌp tə, aɪ weɪdʒɝ ʃid - "

"What are you doing with Rand, now? Have you not used him enough? I don't know why you have not had him gentled, now the Amyrlin's here with all those other Aes Sedai, but you must have a reason. It must be some plot you're hatching. If the Amyrlin knew what you were up to, I wager she'd - "

mɔɪɹeɪn kʌɾ əɹ ɔf. "wʌt pɑsəbəl ɪntʃɹəs kəd ði æmɪɝlɪn əv ɪn ə ʃɛpɝd? ʌv kɔɹs, ɪf i wɝ bɹɔt tə hɝ ətɛnʃən ɪn ðə ɹɔŋ weɪ, hi maɪt bi dʒɛntəld, əɹ ivən kɪld. hiz wʌɾ i ɪz, æftɝ ɔl. ən ðəɹ ɪz kənsɪɾɝəbəl æŋɡɝ əbaʊt læs naɪt. ɛvɹiwʌn ɪz lʊkɪŋ fəɹ hum tə bleɪm." ði ɛɛs sədaɪ fɛl saɪlənt, ən lɛt ðə saɪləns stʃɹɛtʃ. nɪneɪiv stɛɹɾ ət hɝ, ɡɹaɪndɪŋ əɹ tiθ.

Moiraine cut her off. "What possible interest could the Amyrlin have in a shepherd? Of course, if he were brought to her attention in the wrong way, he might be gentled, or even killed. He is what he is, after all. And there is considerable anger about last night. Everyone is looking for whom to blame." The Aes Sedai fell silent, and let the silence stretch. Nynaeve stared at her, grinding her teeth.

"jɛs," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd faɪnəli, "mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ tə lɛɾ ə slipɪŋ laɪən slip. bɛs jə si tə jəɹ pækɪŋ, naʊ." ʃi muvd ɔf ɪn ðə dɝɛkʃən læn hæd ɡɔn, simɪŋ tə ɡlaɪɾ əkɹɔs ðə flɔɹ.

"Yes," Moiraine said finally, "much better to let a sleeping lion sleep. Best you see to your packing, now." She moved off in the direction Lan had gone, seeming to glide across the floor.

ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ, nɪneɪiv swʌŋ əɹ fɪs bæk əɡɛns ðə wɔl; ðə ɹɪŋ dʌɡ əɾ əɹ pɑm. ʃi oʊpən əɹ hæn tə lʊk əɾ ɪt. ðə ɹɪŋ sim tə hiɾ əɹ æŋɡɝ, foʊkəs əɹ heɪt. əl lɝn. jə θɪŋk kəz jə noʊ, jə kən ɪskeɪp mi. bʌɾ əl lɝn bɛɾɝ ðən jə θɪŋk, ən əl pʊl jə daʊn fəɹ wʌt juv dʌn. fəɹ wʌt juv dʌn tə mæt, ən tə pɛɹɪn. fəɹ ɹænd, ðə laɪt hɛlp ɪm ən ðə kɹieɪɾɝ ʃɛltɝ hɪm. ɪspɛʃli fəɹ ɹænd. hɝ hæn kloʊzd ɝaʊn ðə hɛvi sɝkləɾ ʌv ɡoʊld. ən fəɹ mi.

Grimacing, Nynaeve swung her fist back against the wall; the ring dug at her palm. She opened her hand to look at it. The ring seemed to heat her anger, focus her hate. I will learn. You think because you know, you can escape me. But I will learn better than you think, and I will pull you down for what you've done. For what you've done to Mat, and to Perrin. For Rand, the Light help him and the Creator shelter him. Especially for Rand. Her hand closed around the heavy circlet of gold. And for me.

ɛɡwin wɑtʃt ðə lɪvɹid meɪd foʊldɪŋ əɹ dʒɹɛsəz ɪndə ə lɛðɝ-kʌvɝd tʃɹævəl tʃɛst, stɪl ə lɪɾəl ənkʌmftəɹbəl, ivən æftɝ nɪɹli ə mʌnθs pɹæktəs, wɪð sʌmwʌn ɛls duɪŋ wʌt ʃi kəd vɛɹi wɛl əv dʌn hɝsɛlf. ðeɪ wɝ sətʃ bjuɾəfəl dʒɹɛsəz, ɔl ɡɪfs fɹəm ðə leɪɾi əmælisə, dʒʌs laɪk ðə ɡɹeɪ sɪlk ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs ʃi wɔɹ, ðoʊ ðət wɑz pleɪn ɪksɛp fəɹ ə fju waɪt mɔɹnɪŋstɑɹ blɑsəmz wɝkt ɑn ðə bɹɛst. mɛni ʌv ðə dʒɹɛsəz wɝ mʌtʃ mɔɹ ɪlæbɹeɪt. ɛni wʌn ə ðɛm wəd ʃaɪn ət sʌndeɪ, əɹ ət bɛl taɪn. ʃi saɪd, ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ðət ʃi wəd bi ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn fəɹ ðə nɛkst sʌndeɪ, nɑɾ ɛmənz fild. fɹəm ðə lɪɾəl mɔɪɹeɪn hæd toʊld əɹ ə nɑvəs tʃɹeɪnɪŋ - ɔlmoʊs nʌθɪŋ, ɹɪli - ʃi ɪkspɛktəd ʃi maɪt nɑt bi hoʊm fəɹ bɛl taɪn, ɪn ðə spɹɪŋ, əɹ ivən ðə sʌndeɪ æftɝ ðæt.

Egwene watched the liveried maid folding her dresses into a leather-covered travel chest, still a little uncomfortable, even after nearly a month's practice, with someone else doing what she could very well have done herself. They were such beautiful dresses, all gifts from the Lady Amalisa, just like the gray silk riding dress she wore, though that was plain except for a few white morningstar blossoms worked on the breast. Many of the dresses were much more elaborate. Any one of them would shine at Sunday, or at Bel Tine. She sighed, remembering that she would be in Tar Valon for the next Sunday, not Emond's Field. From the little Moiraine had told her of novice training - almost nothing, really - she expected she might not be home for Bel Tine, in the spring, or even the Sunday after that.

nɪneɪiv pʊɾ əɹ hɛɾ ɪndə ðə ɹum. "ɑɹ jə ɹɛɾi?" ʃi keɪm ðə ɹɛst ə ðə weɪ ɪn. "wi mʌs bi daʊn ɪn ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd sun." ʃi wɔɹ ə ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs, tu, ɪn blu sɪlk wɪð ɹɛd lʌvɝsknɑts ɑn ðə bʊzəm. ənʌðɝ ɡɪft fɹəm əmælisə.

Nynaeve put her head into the room. "Are you ready?" She came the rest of the way in. "We must be down in the courtyard soon." She wore a riding dress, too, in blue silk with red loversknots on the bosom. Another gift from Amalisa.

"nɪɹli, nɪneɪiv. aɪm ɔlmoʊst sɑɹi tə bi ɡoʊɪŋ. aɪ doʊn səpoʊz wɪl əv mɛni tʃænsəz ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn tə wɛɹ ðə naɪs dʒɹɛsəz əmælisə ɡeɪv ʌs." ʃi ɡeɪv ən əbɹʌp læf. "stɪl, wɪzdəm, aɪ woʊn mɪs biɪŋ eɪbəl tə beɪð wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ maɪ ʃoʊldɝ ðə hoʊl taɪm."

"Nearly, Nynaeve. I am almost sorry to be going. I don't suppose we'll have many chances in Tar Valon to wear the nice dresses Amalisa gave us." She gave an abrupt laugh. "Still, Wisdom, I won't miss being able to bathe without looking over my shoulder the whole time."

"mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ tə beɪð əloʊn," nɪneɪiv sɛd bɹɪskli. hɝ feɪs dɪd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ, bʌɾ æftɝ ə moʊmən əɹ tʃiks kʌlɝd.

"Much better to bathe alone," Nynaeve said briskly. Her face did not change, but after a moment her cheeks colored.

ɛɡwin smaɪld. ʃiz θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt læn. ɪt wɑz stɪl ɑd tə θɪŋk ə nɪneɪiv, ðə wɪzdəm, munɪŋ æftɝ ə mæn. ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ɪt wəd bi waɪz tə pʊɾ ɪt tə nɪneɪiv ɪn kwaɪt ðət weɪ, bʌɾ ə leɪt, səmtaɪmz ðə wɪzdəm æktəɾ əz stʃɹeɪnʒli əz ɛni ɡɝl u hæd sɛɾ əɹ hɑɹɾ ɑn ə pɝtɪkjəlɝ mæn. ən wʌn u dʌzn əv ɪnʌf sɛns tə bi wɝði ʌv hɝ, ət ðæt. ʃi lʌvz hɪm, ən aɪ kən si hi lʌvz hɝ, soʊ waɪ kæn i hæv sɛns ɪnʌf tə spik ʌp?

Egwene smiled. She's thinking about Lan. It was still odd to think of Nynaeve, the Wisdom, mooning after a man. She did not think it would be wise to put it to Nynaeve in quite that way, but of late, sometimes the Wisdom acted as strangely as any girl who had set her heart on a particular man. And one who doesn't have enough sense to be worthy of her, at that. She loves him, and I can see he loves her, so why can't he have sense enough to speak up?

"aɪ doʊn θɪŋk jə ʃəd kɔl mi wɪzdəm ɛni lɔŋɡɝ," nɪneɪiv sɛd sʌɾənli.

"I don't think you should call me Wisdom any longer," Nynaeve said suddenly.

ɛɡwin blɪŋkt. ɪt wɑz nɑt ɹikwaɪɝd, ɪɡzækli, ən nɪneɪiv nɛvɝ ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn ɪɾ ənlɛs ʃi wɑz æŋɡɹi, əɹ biɪŋ fɔɹməl, bʌt ðɪs. . . . "waɪ ɛvɝ nɑt?"

Egwene blinked. It was not required, exactly, and Nynaeve never insisted on it unless she was angry, or being formal, but this. . . . "Why ever not?"

"ju ɑɹ ə wʊmən, naʊ." nɪneɪiv ɡlænst əɾ əɹ ənbɹeɪɾɪd hɛɹ, ən ɛɡwin ɹɪzɪstɪd ði ɝdʒ tə hɝidli twɪst ɪɾ ɪndə ə sɛmbləns ʌv ə bɹeɪd. ɛɛs sədaɪ wɔɹ ðɛɹ hɛɹ ɛni weɪ ðeɪ wɑntəd, bʌt wɛɹɪŋ hɝz lus hæd bɪkʌm ə sɪmbəl ə stɑɹɾɪŋ ɑn ə nu laɪf. "ju ɑɹ ə wʊmən," nɪneɪiv ɹɪpiɾɪd fɝmli. "wi ɑɹ tu wɪmən, ə lɔŋ weɪ fɹəm ɛmənz fild, ən ɪɾəl bi lɔŋɡɝ stɪl bɪfɔɹ wi si hoʊm əɡɛn. ɪɾəl bi bɛɾɝ ɪf jə sɪmpli kɔl mi nɪneɪiv."

"You are a woman, now." Nynaeve glanced at her unbraided hair, and Egwene resisted the urge to hurriedly twist it into a semblance of a braid. Aes Sedai wore their hair any way they wanted, but wearing hers loose had become a symbol of starting on a new life. "You are a woman," Nynaeve repeated firmly. "We are two women, a long way from Emond's Field, and it will be longer still before we see home again. It will be better if you simply call me Nynaeve."

"wi wɪl si hoʊm əɡɛn, nɪneɪiv. wi wɪl."

"We will see home again, Nynaeve. We will."

"doʊn tʃɹaɪ tə kʌmfɝt ðə wɪzdəm, ɡɝl," nɪneɪiv sɛd ɡɹʌflaɪ, bʌt ʃi smaɪld.

"Don't try to comfort the Wisdom, girl," Nynaeve said gruffly, but she smiled.

ðəɹ wɑz ə nɑk ət ðə dɔɹ, bʌt bɪfɔɹ ɛɡwin kəɾ oʊpən ɪt, nɪʃʊɹə keɪm ɪn, ædʒəteɪʃən ɔl oʊvɝ əɹ feɪs. "ɛɡwin, ðət jʌŋ mæn ə jʊɹz ɪz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kʌm ɪndə ðə wɪmənz əpɑɹtməns." ʃi saʊndəd skændəlaɪzd. "ænd wɛɹɪŋ ə sɔɹd. dʒʌs kəz ði æmɪɝlɪn lɛɾ ɪm ɛntɝ ðət weɪ. . . . lɔɹd ɹænd ʃəd noʊ bɛɾɝ. hiz kɑzɪŋ ən ʌpɹɔɹ. ɛɡwin, jə mʌst spik tə hɪm."

There was a knock at the door, but before Egwene could open it, Nisura came in, agitation all over her face. "Egwene, that young man of yours is trying to come into the women's apartments." She sounded scandalized. "And wearing a sword. Just because the Amyrlin let him enter that way. . . . Lord Rand should know better. He is causing an uproar. Egwene, you must speak to him."

"lɔɹd ɹænd," nɪneɪiv snɔɹɾɪd. "ðæt jʌŋ mæn ɪz ɡɹoʊɪŋ tu bɪɡ fəɹ ɪz bɹitʃɪz. wən aɪ ɡɛt maɪ hænz ɑn hɪm, əl lɔɹd hɪm."

"Lord Rand," Nynaeve snorted. "That young man is growing too big for his breeches. When I get my hands on him, I'll lord him."

ɛɡwin pʊɾ ə hæn ɑn nɪneɪivz ɑɹm. "lɛt mi spik tə hɪm, nɪneɪiv. əloʊn."

Egwene put a hand on Nynaeve's arm. "Let me speak to him, Nynaeve. Alone."

"oʊ, vɛɹi wɛl. ðə bɛst ə mɛn ɑɹ nɑt mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ ðən haʊsbɹoʊkən." nɪneɪiv pɔzd, ən æɾəd hæf tə hɝsɛlf, "bʌt ðɛn, ðə bɛst ə ðɛm ɑɹ wɝθ ðə tʃɹʌbəl ə haʊsbɹeɪkɪŋ."

"Oh, very well. The best of men are not much better than housebroken." Nynaeve paused, and added half to herself, "But then, the best of them are worth the trouble of housebreaking."

ɛɡwin ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ əz ʃi fɑloʊd nɪʃʊɹə ɪndə ðə hɔl. ivən hæf ə jɪɹ bɪfɔɹ, nɪneɪiv wəd nɛvɝ əv æɾəd ðə sɛkən pɑɹt. bʌt ʃɪl nɛvɝ haʊsbɹeɪk læn. hɝ θɔts tɝn tə ɹænd. kɑzɪŋ ən ʌpɹɔɹ, wɑz hi? "haʊs bɹeɪk hɪm?" ʃi mʌɾɝd. "ɪf i hæzən lɝn mænɝz baɪ ðɪs taɪm, əl skɪn ɪm əlaɪv."

Egwene shook her head as she followed Nisura into the hall. Even half a year before, Nynaeve would never have added the second part. But she'll never housebreak Lan. Her thoughts turned to Rand. Causing an uproar, was he? "House break him?" she muttered. "If he hasn't learned manners by this time, I'll skin him alive."

"səmtaɪmz ðəɾ ɪz wʌɾ ɪt teɪks," nɪʃʊɹə sɛd, wɔkɪŋ kwɪkli. "mɛn ɑɹ nɛvɝ mɔɹ ðən hæf-sɪvəlaɪzd əntɪl ðəɹ wɛɾəd." ʃi ɡeɪv ɛɡwin ə saɪɾɛlɔŋ ɡlæns. "du jə ɪntɛn tə mɛɹi lɔɹd ɹænd? aɪ də nɑt min tə pɹaɪ, bʌt jə ɑɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ən ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛldəm wɛd - nʌn bʌt səm ə ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ, ðəɾ aɪv ɛvɝ hɝd, ən nɑt mɛni ʌv əm - ænd. . . ."

"Sometimes that is what it takes," Nisura said, walking quickly. "Men are never more than half-civilized until they're wedded." She gave Egwene a sidelong glance. "Do you intend to marry Lord Rand? I do not mean to pry, but you are going to the White Tower, and Aes Sedai seldom wed - none but some of the Green Ajah, that I've ever heard, and not many of them - and. . . ."

ɛɡwin kəd səplaɪ ðə ɹɛst. ʃi hæd hɝd ðə tɔk ɪn ðə wɪmənz əpɑɹtməns əbaʊɾ ə suɾəbəl waɪf fəɹ ɹænd. ət fɝst ɪt hæd kɑz stæbz ə dʒɛləsi, ən æŋɡɝ. hi hæd bɪn ɔl bʌt pɹɑməs tə hɝ sɪns ðeɪ wɝ tʃɪlʒɹən. bʌt ʃi wɑz gɑnə bi ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən i wɑz wʌɾ i wɑz. ə mæn u kəd tʃænəl. ʃi kəd mɛɹi hɪm. ən wɑtʃ ɪm ɡoʊ mæd, wɑtʃ ɪm daɪ. ði oʊnli weɪ tə stɑp ɪt wəd bi tə hæv ɪm dʒɛntəld. aɪ kæn də ðət tə hɪm. aɪ kænt! "aɪ də nɑt noʊ," ʃi sɛd sædli.

Egwene could supply the rest. She had heard the talk in the women's apartments about a suitable wife for Rand. At first it had caused stabs of jealousy, and anger. He had been all but promised to her since they were children. But she was going to be an Aes Sedai, and he was what he was. A man who could channel. She could marry him. And watch him go mad, watch him die. The only way to stop it would be to have him gentled. I can't do that to him. I can't! "I do not know," she said sadly.

nɪʃʊɹə nɑɾəd. "noʊ wʌn wɪl poʊtʃ wɛɹ juv ə kleɪm, bʌt jə ɑɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə ðə taʊɝ, ən hɪl meɪk ə ɡʊd hʌzbənd. wʌns hiz bɪn tʃɹeɪnd. ðəɹ i ɪz."

Nisura nodded. "No one will poach where you have a claim, but you are going to the Tower, and he will make a good husband. Once he has been trained. There he is."

ðə wɪmən ɡæðɝɾ ɝaʊn ði ɛntʃɹəns tə ðə wɪmənz əpɑɹtməns, boʊθ ɪnsaɪɾ ən aʊt, wɝ ɔl wɑtʃɪŋ θɹi mɛn ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ aʊtsaɪd. ɹænd, wɪð ɪz sɔɹd bʌkəld oʊvɝ ɪz ɹɛd koʊt, wɑz biɪŋ kənfɹʌntəd baɪ eɪɡəlmɝ ən keɪdʒɪn. niðɝ ə ðɛm wɔɹ ə sɔɹd; ivən æftɝ wʌt hæd hæpən ɪn ðə naɪt, ðiz wɝ stɪl ðə wɪmənz əpɑɹtməns. ɛɡwin stɑpt ət ðə bæk ə ðə kɹaʊd.

The women gathered around the entrance to the women's apartments, both inside and out, were all watching three men in the hallway outside. Rand, with his sword buckled over his red coat, was being confronted by Agelmar and Kajin. Neither of them wore a sword; even after what had happened in the night, these were still the women's apartments. Egwene stopped at the back of the crowd.

"ju ʌndɝstænd waɪ jə kænɑt ɡoʊ ɪn," eɪɡəlmɝ wɑz seɪɪŋ. "aɪ noʊ ðət θɪŋz ɑɹ dɪfɹən ɪn ændɝ, bʌt jə də ʌndɝstænd?"

"You understand why you cannot go in," Agelmar was saying. "I know that things are different in Andor, but you do understand?"

"aɪ dɪdn tʃɹaɪ tə ɡoʊ ɪn." ɹænd saʊndəɾ əz ɪf i hæɾ ɪkspleɪn ɔl ðɪs mɔɹ ðən wʌns ɔlɹɛɾi. "aɪ toʊl ðə leɪɾi nɪʃʊɹə aɪ wɑntəd tə si ɛɡwin, ən ʃi sɛɾ ɛɡwin wɑz bɪzi, ən aɪɾ əv tə weɪt. ɔl aɪ dɪd wɑz ʃaʊt fəɹ əɹ fɹəm ðə dɔɹ. aɪ dɪd nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə ɛntɝ. juɾ əv θɔɾ aɪ wɑz neɪmɪŋ ðə dɑɹk wʌn, ðə weɪ ðeɪ ɔl stɑɹɾəd ɪn ɑn mi."

"I didn't try to go in." Rand sounded as if he had explained all this more than once already. "I told the Lady Nisura I wanted to see Egwene, and she said Egwene was busy, and I'd have to wait. All I did was shout for her from the door. I did not try to enter. You'd have thought I was naming the Dark One, the way they all started in on me."

"wɪmən əv ðɛɹ oʊn weɪz," keɪdʒɪn sɛd. hi wɑz tɔl fəɹ ə ʃaɪnɝən, ɔlmoʊst əz tɔl əz ɹænd, læŋki ən sæloʊ. hɪz tɑpnɑt wɑz blæk əz pɪtʃ. "ðeɪ sɛt ðə ɹulz fəɹ ðə wɪmənz əpɑɹtməns, ən wi əbaɪd baɪ ðɛm ivən wən ðeɪ ɑɹ fulɪʃ." ə nʌmbɝ ʌv aɪbɹaʊz wɝ ɹeɪzd əmʌŋ ðə wɪmən, ən i heɪstəli klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊt. "ju mʌst sɛn ə mɛsədʒ ɪn ɪf jə wɪʃ tə spik tə wʌn ə ðə wɪmən, bʌɾ ɪɾəl bi dɪlɪvɝd wən ðeɪ tʃuz, ən əntɪl ɪɾ ɪz, jə mʌst weɪt. ðəɾ ɪz əɹ kʌstəm."

"Women have their own ways," Kajin said. He was tall for a Shienaran, almost as tall as Rand, lanky and sallow. His topknot was black as pitch. "They set the rules for the women's apartments, and we abide by them even when they are foolish." A number of eyebrows were raised among the women, and he hastily cleared his throat. "You must send a message in if you wish to speak to one of the women, but it will be delivered when they choose, and until it is, you must wait. That is our custom."

"aɪ hæv tə si hɝ," ɹænd sɛd stʌbɝnli. "wɝ livɪŋ sun. nɑt sun ɪnʌf fəɹ mi, bʌɾ aɪ stɪl əv tə si ɛɡwin. wɪl ɡɛt ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ ən ðə dæɡɝ bæk, ən ðət wɪl bi ði ɛn ʌv ɪt. ði ɛn ʌv ɪt. bʌɾ aɪ wɑnə si hɝ bɪfɔɹ aɪ ɡoʊ." ɛɡwin fɹaʊnd; hi saʊndəɾ ɑd.

"I have to see her," Rand said stubbornly. "We're leaving soon. Not soon enough for me, but I still have to see Egwene. We will get the Horn of Valere and the dagger back, and that will be the end of it. The end of it. But I want to see her before I go." Egwene frowned; he sounded odd.

"noʊ nid tə bi soʊ fɪɹs," keɪdʒɪn sɛd. "ju ən ɪŋtʃɹ wɪl faɪn ðə hɔɹn, əɹ nɑt. ən ɪf nɑt, ðən ənʌðɝ wɪl ɹɪtʃɹiv ɪt. ðə wil wivz əz ðə wil wɪlz, ən wəɹ bʌt θɹɛdz ɪn ðə pæɾɝn."

"No need to be so fierce," Kajin said. "You and Ingtar will find the Horn, or not. And if not, then another will retrieve it. The Wheel weaves as the Wheel wills, and we are but threads in the Pattern."

"du nɑt lɛt ðə hɔɹn siz ju, ɹænd," eɪɡəlmɝ sɛd. "ɪt kən teɪk hoʊld ʌv ə mæn - aɪ noʊ haʊ ɪt kən - ən ðəɾ ɪz nɑt ðə weɪ. ə mæn mʌst sik duɾi, nɑt ɡlɔɹi. wʌt wɪl hæpən, wɪl hæpən. ɪf ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ ɪz mɛn tə bi saʊndəd fəɹ ðə laɪt, ðən ɪɾəl bi."

"Do not let the Horn seize you, Rand," Agelmar said. "It can take hold of a man - I know how it can - and that is not the way. A man must seek duty, not glory. What will happen, will happen. If the Horn of Valere is meant to be sounded for the Light, then it will be."

"hɪɹ ɪz jəɹ ɛɡwin," keɪdʒɪn sɛd, spɑɾɪŋ hɝ.

"Here is your Egwene," Kajin said, spotting her.

eɪɡəlmɝ lʊkt ɝaʊnd, ən nɑɾəd wən i sɔ hɝ wɪð nɪʃʊɹə. "aɪ wɪl liv jə ɪn əɹ hænz, ɹænd ælθɹ. ɹɪmɛmbɝ, hɪɹ, hɝ wɝdz ɑɹ lɔ, nɑt jʊɹz. leɪɾi nɪʃʊɹə, də nɑt bi tu hɑɹɾ ɑn hɪm. hi oʊnli wɪʃt tə si hɪz jʌŋ wʊmən, ən i dʌz nɑt noʊ əɹ weɪz."

Agelmar looked around, and nodded when he saw her with Nisura. "I will leave you in her hands, Rand al'Thor. Remember, here, her words are law, not yours. Lady Nisura, do not be too hard on him. He only wished to see his young woman, and he does not know our ways."

ɛɡwin fɑloʊd nɪʃʊɹə əz ðə ʃaɪnɝən wʊmən θɹɛɾəd əɹ weɪ θɹu ðə wɑtʃɪŋ wɪmən. nɪʃʊɹə ɪnklaɪn əɹ hɛd bɹifli tə eɪɡəlmɝ ən keɪdʒɪn; ʃi pɔɪntɪdli dɪd nɑɾ ɪnklud ɹænd. hɝ vɔɪs wɑz taɪt. "lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ. lɔɹd keɪdʒɪn. hi ʃəd noʊ ðɪs mʌtʃ ʌv əɹ weɪz baɪ naʊ, bʌt hiz tu bɪɡ tə spæŋk, soʊ əl lɛɾ ɛɡwin dil wɪð hɪm."

Egwene followed Nisura as the Shienaran woman threaded her way through the watching women. Nisura inclined her head briefly to Agelmar and Kajin; she pointedly did not include Rand. Her voice was tight. "Lord Agelmar. Lord Kajin. He should know this much of our ways by now, but he is too big to spank, so I will let Egwene deal with him."

eɪɡəlmɝ ɡeɪv ɹænd ə fɑðɝli pæɾ ɑn ðə ʃoʊldɝ. "ju si. jəl spik wɪð hɝ, ɪf nɑɾ ɪɡzækli ɪn ðə weɪ jə wɪʃt. kʌm, keɪdʒɪn. wɪv mʌtʃ tə si tə jɛt. ði æmɪɝlɪn stɪl ɪnsɪsts ɑn. . . ." hɪz vɔɪs tʃɹeɪld əweɪ əz i ən ði ʌðɝ mæn lɛft. ɹænd stʊd ðɛɹ, lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɛɡwin.

Agelmar gave Rand a fatherly pat on the shoulder. "You see. You will speak with her, if not exactly in the way you wished. Come, Kajin. We have much to see to yet. The Amyrlin still insists on. . . ." His voice trailed away as he and the other man left. Rand stood there, looking at Egwene.

ðə wɪmən wɝ stɪl wɑtʃɪŋ, ɛɡwin ɹilaɪzd. wɑtʃɪŋ əɹ əz wɛl əz ɹænd. weɪɾɪŋ tə si wʌt ʃi wəd du. soʊ aɪm səpoʊz tə dil wɪð hɪm, æm aɪ? jɛt ʃi fɛlt əɹ hɑɹt ɡoʊɪŋ aʊt tə hɪm. hɪz hɛɹ niɾəd bɹʌʃɪŋ. hɪz feɪs ʃoʊɾ æŋɡɝ, dɪfaɪəns, ən wɪɹinəs. "wɔk wɪð mi," ʃi toʊl hɪm. ə mɝmɝ stɑɹɾəd ʌp bɪhaɪn əm əz i wɔk daʊn ðə hɔl bɪsaɪd hɝ, əweɪ fɹəm ðə wɪmənz əpɑɹtməns. ɹænd sim tə bi stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ wɪð hɪmsɛlf, hʌntɪŋ fəɹ wʌt tə seɪ.

The women were still watching, Egwene realized. Watching her as well as Rand. Waiting to see what she would do. So I'm supposed to deal with him, am I? Yet she felt her heart going out to him. His hair needed brushing. His face showed anger, defiance, and weariness. "Walk with me," she told him. A murmur started up behind them as he walked down the hall beside her, away from the women's apartments. Rand seemed to be struggling with himself, hunting for what to say.

"aɪv hɝɾ əbaʊt jəɹ . . . ɛksplɔɪts," ʃi sɛd faɪnəli. "ɹʌnɪŋ θɹu ðə wɪmənz əpɑɹtməns læs naɪt wɪð ə sɔɹd. wɛɹɪŋ ə sɔɹd tə ən ɑɾiəns wɪð ði æmɪɝlɪn sit." hi stɪl sɛd nʌθɪŋ, oʊnli wɔkt əlɔŋ fɹaʊnɪŋ ət ðə flɔɹ. "ʃi dɪdnt . . . hɝt ju, dɪd ʃi?" ʃi kəd nɑt meɪk hɝsɛlf æsk ɪf i hæd bɪn dʒɛntəld; hi lʊkt ɛniθɪŋ bʌt dʒɛntəl, bʌt ʃi hæd noʊ aɪdiə wʌɾ ə mæn lʊk laɪk æftɝwɝdz.

"I've heard about your . . . exploits," she said finally. "Running through the women's apartments last night with a sword. Wearing a sword to an audience with the Amyrlin Seat." He still said nothing, only walked along frowning at the floor. "She didn't . . . hurt you, did she?" She could not make herself ask if he had been gentled; he looked anything but gentle, but she had no idea what a man looked like afterwards.

hi ɡeɪv ə dʒɝk. "noʊ. ʃi dɪdnt. . . . ɛɡwin, ði æmɪɝlɪn. . . ." hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ʃi dɪdn hɝt mi."

He gave a jerk. "No. She didn't. . . . Egwene, the Amyrlin. . . ." He shook his head. "She didn't hurt me."

ʃi hæd ðə filɪŋ i hæd bɪn gɑnə seɪ sʌmθɪŋ ɛls ɪntaɪɝli. juʒəwəli ʃi kəd fɛɹəɾ aʊt wʌtɛvɝ i wɑntəd tə haɪd fɹəm hɝ, bʌt wən i ɹɪli wɑntəd tə bi stʌbɝn, ʃi kəd mɔɹ izəli dɪɡ ə bɹɪk aʊɾ ʌv ə wɔl wɪð əɹ fɪŋɡɝneɪlz. baɪ ðə sɛɾ ə hɪz dʒɔ, hi wɑz əɾ ɪz moʊst stʌbɝn ɹaɪt naʊ.

She had the feeling he had been going to say something else entirely. Usually she could ferret out whatever he wanted to hide from her, but when he really wanted to be stubborn, she could more easily dig a brick out of a wall with her fingernails. By the set of his jaw, he was at his most stubborn right now.

"wʌt dɪd ʃi wɑnt wɪð ju, ɹænd?"

"What did she want with you, Rand?"

"nʌθɪŋ ɪmpɔɹɾənt. tɑvɝən. ʃi wɑntəd tə si tɑvɝən." hɪz feɪs sɔfən əz i lʊk daʊn ət hɝ. "wʌɾ əbaʊt ju, ɛɡwin? ɑɹ jə ɔl ɹaɪt? mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd jə wəd bi, bʌt jə wɝ soʊ stɪl. aɪ θɔt jə wɝ dɛd, ət fɝst."

"Nothing important. Ta'veren. She wanted to see ta'veren." His face softened as he looked down at her. "What about you, Egwene? Are you all right? Moiraine said you would be, but you were so still. I thought you were dead, at first."

"wɛl, ɪm nɑt." ʃi læft. ʃi kəd nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɛniθɪŋ ðət hæd hæpən æftɝ ʃi hæɾ æsk mæt tə ɡoʊ tə ðə dʌnʒənz wɪð hɝ, nɑɾ əntɪl weɪkɪŋ ɪn əɹ oʊn bɛd ðət mɔɹnɪŋ. fɹəm wʌt ʃi hæd hɝɾ ə ðə naɪt, ʃi wɑz ɔlmoʊst ɡlæd ʃi kəd nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ. "mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd ʃi wʊɾə lɛf mi ə hɛdeɪk fəɹ biɪŋ fulɪʃ ɪf ʃi cʊɾə hil ðə ɹɛst ən nɑt ðæt, bʌt ʃi kʊdnt."

"Well, I'm not." She laughed. She could not remember anything that had happened after she had asked Mat to go to the dungeons with her, not until waking in her own bed that morning. From what she had heard of the night, she was almost glad she could not remember. "Moiraine said she would have left me a headache for being foolish if she could have Healed the rest and not that, but she couldn't."

"aɪ toʊl jə feɪn wɑz deɪnʒɝəs," hi mʌɾɝd. "aɪ toʊl ju, bʌt jə wʊdn lɪsən."

"I told you Fain was dangerous," he muttered. "I told you, but you wouldn't listen."

"ɪf ðæts ðə weɪ jə ɑɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə tɔk," ʃi sɛd fɝmli, "aɪ wɪl ɡɪv jə bæk tə nɪʃʊɹə. ʃi woʊn tɔk tə jə ðə weɪ aɪ æm. ðə læs mæn u tʃɹaɪd tə pʊʃ ɪz weɪ ɪndə ðə wɪmənz əpɑɹtməns spɛn ə mʌnθ ʌp tə hɪz ɛlboʊz ɪn soʊpi wɔɾɝ, hɛlpɪŋ wɪð ðə wɪmənz lɔnʒɹi, ən i wɑz oʊnli tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪn ɪz bɪtʃɹɑθd ən meɪk ʌp ən ɑɹɡjəmənt. ət list i nu ɪnʌf nɑt tə wɛɹ ɪz sɔɹd. ðə laɪt noʊz wʌt ðeɪd də tə ju."

"If that's the way you are going to talk," she said firmly, "I will give you back to Nisura. She won't talk to you the way I am. The last man who tried to push his way into the women's apartments spent a month up to his elbows in soapy water, helping with the women's laundry, and he was only trying to find his betrothed and make up an argument. At least he knew enough not to wear his sword. The Light knows what they'd do to you."

"ɛvɹibɑɾi wɑns tə də sʌmθɪŋ tə mi," hi ɡɹaʊld. "ɛvɹibɑɾi wɑns tə juz mi fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ. wɛl, aɪ woʊn bi juzd. wʌns wi faɪn ðə hɔɹn, ən mæts dæɡɝ, əl nɛvɝ bi juzd əɡɛn."

"Everybody wants to do something to me," he growled. "Everybody wants to use me for something. Well, I won't be used. Once we find the Horn, and Mat's dagger, I'll never be used again."

wɪð ən ɪɡzæspɝeɪɾɪd ɡɹʌnt, ʃi kɑɾ ɪz ʃoʊldɝz ən meɪɾ ɪm feɪs hɝ. ʃi ɡlɛɹɾ ʌp ət hɪm. "ɪf jə doʊn stɑɹt tɔkɪŋ sɛns, ɹænd ælθɹ, aɪ swɛɹ əl bɑks jəɹ ɪɹz."

With an exasperated grunt, she caught his shoulders and made him face her. She glared up at him. "If you don't start talking sense, Rand al'Thor, I swear I will box your ears."

"naʊ jə saʊn laɪk nɪneɪiv." hi læft. əz i lʊk daʊn ət hɝ, ðoʊ, hɪz læftɝ feɪɾəd. "aɪ səpoʊz - aɪ səpoʊz əl nɛvɝ si jə əɡɛn. aɪ noʊ juv tə ɡoʊ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn. aɪ noʊ ðæt. ən jəl bɪkʌm ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. aɪm dʌn wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɛɡwin. aɪ woʊn bi ə pʌpət fəɹ ðɛm, nɑt fəɹ mɔɪɹeɪn, əɹ ɛni ʌv ðɛm."

"Now you sound like Nynaeve." He laughed. As he looked down at her, though, his laughter faded. "I suppose - I suppose I'll never see you again. I know you have to go to Tar Valon. I know that. And you'll become an Aes Sedai. I am done with Aes Sedai, Egwene. I won't be a puppet for them, not for Moiraine, or any of them."

hi lʊk soʊ lɔst ʃi wɑntəd tə pʊɾ ɪz hɛɾ ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝ, ən soʊ stʌbɝn ʃi ɹɪli dɪd wɑnə bɑks ɪz ɪɹz. "lɪsən tə mi, jə ɡɹeɪɾ ɑks. aɪm gɑnə bi ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən əl faɪn ə weɪ tə hɛlp ju. aɪ wɪl."

He looked so lost she wanted to put his head on her shoulder, and so stubborn she really did want to box his ears. "Listen to me, you great ox. I am going to be an Aes Sedai, and I'll find a way to help you. I will."

"ðə nɛks taɪm jə si mi, jəl laɪkli wɑnə dʒɛntəl mi."

"The next time you see me, you will likely want to gentle me."

ʃi lʊkt ɝaʊn heɪstəli; ðeɪ wɝ əloʊn ɪn ðɛɹ stʃɹɛtʃ ə ðə hɔl. "ɪf jə doʊnt wɑtʃ jəɹ tʌŋ, əl nɑt bi eɪbəl tə hɛlp ju. dʒju wɑn ɛvɹiwʌn tə noʊ?"

She looked around hastily; they were alone in their stretch of the hall. "If you don't watch your tongue, I will not be able to help you. Do you want everyone to know?"

"tu mɛni noʊ ɔlɹɛɾi," hi sɛd. "ɛɡwin, aɪ wɪʃ θɪŋz wɝ dɪfɹənt, bʌt ðeɪ ɑɹənt. aɪ wɪʃ. . . . teɪk kɛɹ ə jɝsɛlf. ən pɹɑməs mi jə woʊn tʃuz ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ."

"Too many know already," he said. "Egwene, I wish things were different, but they aren't. I wish. . . . Take care of yourself. And promise me you won't choose the Red Ajah."

tɪɹz blɝɾ əɹ vɪʒən əz ʃi θɹu hɝ ɑɹmz ɝaʊn hɪm. "ju teɪk kɛɹ ə jɝsɛlf," ʃi sɛd fɪɹsli ɪndə hɪz tʃɛst. "ɪf jə doʊnt, əl - aɪl. . . ." ʃi θɔt ʃi hɝɾ ɪm mɝmɝ, "aɪ lʌv ju," ən ðən i wɑz fɝmli ənɹæpɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz, dʒɛnli muvɪŋ əɹ əweɪ fɹəm hɪm. hi tɝn ən stʃɹoʊɾ əweɪ fɹəm hɝ, ɔlmoʊst ɹʌnɪŋ.

Tears blurred her vision as she threw her arms around him. "You take care of yourself," she said fiercely into his chest. "If you don't, I'll - I'll. . . ." She thought she heard him murmur, "I love you," and then he was firmly unwrapping her arms, gently moving her away from him. He turned and strode away from her, almost running.

ʃi dʒʌmpt wən nɪʃʊɹə tʌtʃt əɹ ɑɹm. "hi lʊks əz ɪf jə sɛɾ ɪm ə tæsk i woʊn ɛndʒɔɪ. bʌt jə mʌsnt lɛɾ ɪm si jə kɹaɪ oʊvɝ ɪt. ðət nɪɡeɪts ðə pɝpəs. kʌm. nɪneɪiv wɑns ju."

She jumped when Nisura touched her arm. "He looks as if you set him a task he won't enjoy. But you mustn't let him see you cry over it. That negates the purpose. Come. Nynaeve wants you."

skɹʌbɪŋ əɹ tʃiks, ɛɡwin fɑloʊd ði ʌðɝ wʊmən. teɪk kɛɹ ə jɝsɛlf, jə wʊl-hɛɾəd lʌmɑks. laɪt, teɪk kɛɹ ə hɪm.

Scrubbing her cheeks, Egwene followed the other woman. Take care of yourself, you wool-headed lummox. Light, take care of him.


tʃæptɝ naɪn


CHAPTER 9

livɛteɪkɪŋz


Leavetakings

ði aʊɾɝ kɔɹtʃjɑɹd wɑz ɪn ɔɹɾɝd tɝmɔɪl wən ɹænd faɪnəli ɹitʃt ɪt wɪð ɪz sæɾəlbæɡz ən ðə bʌndəl kənteɪnɪŋ ðə hɑɹp ən flut. ðə sʌn klaɪm təwɔɹd mɪddeɪ. mɛn hɝiɾ ɝaʊn ðə hɔɹsəz, tʌɡɪŋ ət sæɾəl ɡɝθs ən pækhɑɹnəs, vɔɪsəz ɹeɪzd. ʌðɝz dɑɹɾɪd wɪð læst-mɪnəɾ ədɪʃənz tə ðə pæksæɾəlz, əɹ wɔɾɝ fəɹ ðə mɛn wɝkɪŋ, əɹ dæʃt ɔf tə fɛtʃ sʌmθɪŋ dʒʌst ɹɪmɛmbɝd. bʌɾ ɛvɹiwʌn sim tə noʊ ɪɡzækli wʌt ðeɪ wɝ duɪŋ ən wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ. ðə ɡɑɹdwɔks ən ɑɹtʃɝz' bælkəniz wɝ kɹaʊɾəd əɡɛn, ən ɪksaɪtmən kɹækəld ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ ɛɹ. hʊvz klæɾɝd ɑn ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz. wʌn ə ðə pækhɔɹsɪz bɪɡæn kɪkɪŋ, ən steɪbəlmən ɹæn tə kɑm ɪt. ðə smɛl ə hɔɹsəz hʌŋ θɪk. ɹændz kloʊk tʃɹaɪd tə flæp ɪn ðə bɹiz ðət ɹɪpəl ðə swupɪŋ-hɔk bænɝz ɑn ðə taʊɝz, bʌɾ ɪz baʊ, slʌŋ əkɹɔs ɪz bæk, hɛld ɪt daʊn.

The outer courtyard was in ordered turmoil when Rand finally reached it with his saddlebags and the bundle containing the harp and flute. The sun climbed toward midday. Men hurried around the horses, tugging at saddle girths and packharness, voices raised. Others darted with last-minute additions to the packsaddles, or water for the men working, or dashed off to fetch something just remembered. But everyone seemed to know exactly what they were doing and where they were going. The guardwalks and archers' balconies were crowded again, and excitement crackled in the morning air. Hooves clattered on the paving stones. One of the packhorses began kicking, and stablemen ran to calm it. The smell of horses hung thick. Rand's cloak tried to flap in the breeze that rippled the swooping-hawk banners on the towers, but his bow, slung across his back, held it down.

fɹəm aʊtsaɪd ði oʊpən ɡeɪts keɪm ðə saʊnz ə ði æmɪɝlɪnz pɪkmɛn ən ɑɹtʃɝz fɔɹmɪŋ ʌp ɪn ðə skwɛɹ. ðeɪ hæd mɑɹtʃt ɝaʊn fɹəm ə saɪd ɡeɪt. wʌn ə ðə tʃɹʌmpəɾɝz tɛstəɾ ɪz hɔɹn.

From outside the open gates came the sounds of the Amyrlin's pikemen and archers forming up in the square. They had marched around from a side gate. One of the trumpeters tested his horn.

səm ə ðə wɔɹɾɝz ɡlænst ət ɹænd əz i wɔkt əkɹɔs ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd; ə fju ɹeɪzd aɪbɹaʊz wən ðeɪ sɔ ðə hɛɹən-mɑɹk sɔɹd, bʌt nʌn spoʊk. hæf wɔɹ ðə kloʊks ðət wɝ soʊ kwizi-meɪkɪŋ tə lʊk æt. mændɑɹb, lænz stæljən, wɑz ðɛɹ, tɔl, ən blæk, ən fɪɹs-aɪd, bʌt ðə mæn hɪmsɛlf wɑz nɑt, ən nʌn ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, nʌn ə ðə wɪmən, wɝ ɪn ɛvəɾəns jɛɾ iðɝ. mɔɪɹeɪnz waɪt mɛɹ, ɑldib, stɛp deɪntəli bɪsaɪd ðə stæljən.

Some of the Warders glanced at Rand as he walked across the courtyard; a few raised eyebrows when they saw the heron-mark sword, but none spoke. Half wore the cloaks that were so queasy-making to look at. Mandarb, Lan's stallion, was there, tall, and black, and fierce-eyed, but the man himself was not, and none of the Aes Sedai, none of the women, were in evidence yet either. Moiraine's white mare, Aldieb, stepped daintily beside the stallion.

ɹændz beɪ stæljən wɑz wɪð ði ʌðɝ ɡɹup ɑn ðə fɑɹ saɪɾ ə ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd, wɪð ɪŋtʃɹ, ən ə bænɝmən hoʊldɪŋ ɪŋtʃɹz ɡɹeɪ aʊl bænɝ, ən twɛnti ʌðɝ ɑɹmɝd mɛn wɪð lænsɪz tɪpt wɪð tu fiɾ ə stil, ɔl maʊntəɾ ɔlɹɛɾi. ðə bɑɹz ə ðɛɹ hɛlməts kʌvɝd ðɛɹ feɪsəz, ən ɡoʊldən sɝkoʊts wɪð ðə blæk hɔk ɑn ðə tʃɛs hɪd ðɛɹ pleɪt-ænd-meɪl. oʊnli ɪŋtʃɹz hɛlmət hæɾ ə kɹɛst, ə kɹɛsən mun əbʌv ɪz bɹaʊ, pɔɪns ʌp. ɹænd ɹɛkəɡnaɪz səm ə ðə mɛn. ɹʌf-tʌŋd ənoʊ, wɪð ə lɔŋ skɑɹ daʊn ɪz feɪs ən oʊnli wʌn aɪ. ɹeɪɡən ən mæsimə. ʌðɝz u hæɾ ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ə wɝd, əɹ pleɪɾ ə ɡeɪm ə stoʊnz. ɹeɪɡən weɪv tə hɪm, ən ənoʊ nɑɾəd, bʌt mæsimə wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn u ɡeɪv ɪm ə koʊl stɛɹ ən tɝn əweɪ. ðɛɹ pækhɔɹsɪz stʊd plɑtʃədli, teɪlz swɪʃɪŋ.

Rand's bay stallion was with the other group on the far side of the courtyard, with Ingtar, and a bannerman holding Ingtar's Gray Owl banner, and twenty other armored men with lances tipped with two feet of steel, all mounted already. The bars of their helmets covered their faces, and golden surcoats with the Black Hawk on the chest hid their plate-and-mail. Only Ingtar's helmet had a crest, a crescent moon above his brow, points up. Rand recognized some of the men. Rough-tongued Uno, with a long scar down his face and only one eye. Ragan and Masema. Others who had exchanged a word, or played a game of stones. Ragan waved to him, and Uno nodded, but Masema was not the only one who gave him a cold stare and turned away. Their packhorses stood placidly, tails swishing.

ðə bɪɡ beɪ dænst əz ɹænd taɪɾ ɪz sæɾəlbæɡz ən bʌndəl bɪhaɪn ðə haɪ-kæntəl sæɾəl. hi pʊɾ ɪz fʊɾ ɪn ðə stɝəp ən mɝmɝd, "izi, ɹɛd," əz i swʌŋ ɪndə ðə sæɾəl, bʌɾ i lɛt ðə stæljən fɹɪsk əweɪ səm ə hɪz steɪbəl-baʊn ɛnɝdʒi.

The big bay danced as Rand tied his saddlebags and bundle behind the high-cantled saddle. He put his foot in the stirrup and murmured, "Easy, Red," as he swung into the saddle, but he let the stallion frisk away some of his stable-bound energy.

tə ɹændz sɝpɹaɪz, lɔɪəl əpɪɹd fɹəm ðə dɝɛkʃən ə ðə steɪbəlz, ɹaɪɾɪŋ tə dʒɔɪn ðɛm. ði oʊɡiɝz hɛɹi-fɛtlɑk maʊnt wɑz əz bɪɡ ən hɛvi əz ə pɹaɪm dɝən stæljən. bɪsaɪɾ ɪt, ɔl ði ʌðɝ ænəməlz lʊk ðə saɪz ə bɛlə, bʌt wɪð lɔɪəl ɪn ðə sæɾəl, ðə hɔɹs simd ɔlmoʊst ə poʊni.

To Rand's surprise, Loial appeared from the direction of the stables, riding to join them. The Ogier's hairy-fetlocked mount was as big and heavy as a prime Dhurran stallion. Beside it, all the other animals looked the size of Bela, but with Loial in the saddle, the horse seemed almost a pony.

lɔɪəl kæɹid noʊ wɛpən ðət ɹænd kəd si; hi hæd nɛvɝ hɝɾ ʌv ɛni oʊɡiɝ juzɪŋ ə wɛpən. ðɛɹ stɛɾɪŋ wɝ pɹətɛkʃən ɪnʌf. ən lɔɪəl hæɾ ɪz oʊn pɹaɪɔɹəɾiz, hɪz oʊn aɪdiəz ʌv wʌt wɑz niɾəd fəɹ ə dʒɝni. ðə pɑkəts ə hɪz lɔŋ koʊt hæɾ ə tɛlteɪl bʌlʒ, ən ɪz sæɾəlbæɡz ʃoʊd ðə skwɛɹ ɪmpɹɪns ə bʊks.

Loial carried no weapon that Rand could see; he had never heard of any Ogier using a weapon. Their stedding were protection enough. And Loial had his own priorities, his own ideas of what was needed for a journey. The pockets of his long coat had a telltale bulge, and his saddlebags showed the square imprints of books.

ði oʊɡiɝ stɑpt ɪz hɔɹs ə lɪɾəl weɪ ɔf ən lʊkt ət ɹænd, hɪz tʌftəɾ ɪɹz twɪtʃɪŋ ənsɝteɪnli.

The Ogier stopped his horse a little way off and looked at Rand, his tufted ears twitching uncertainly.

"aɪ dɪdnt noʊ jə wɝ kʌmɪŋ," ɹænd sɛd. "aɪd θɪŋk jə wʊɾə hæɾ ɪnʌf ə tʃɹævlɪŋ wɪð ʌs. ðɪs taɪm ðɛɹz noʊ tɛlɪŋ haʊ lɔŋ ɪɾəl bi, əɹ wɛɹ wɪl ɛn ʌp."

"I didn't know you were coming," Rand said. "I'd think you would have had enough of traveling with us. This time there's no telling how long it will be, or where we will end up."

lɔɪəlz ɪɹz lɪftəɾ ə lɪɾəl. "ðɛɹ wɑz noʊ tɛlɪŋ wən aɪ fɝs mɛt ju, iðɝ. bɪsaɪdz, wʌt hɛl ðɛn, hoʊlz naʊ. aɪ kæn lɛt ðə tʃæns pæs tə si hɪstɝi æktʃəli  wiv ɪtsɛlf ɝaʊn tɑvɝən. ən tə hɛlp faɪn ðə hɔɹn. . . ."

Loial's ears lifted a little. "There was no telling when I first met you, either. Besides, what held then, holds now. I can't let the chance pass to see history actually weave itself around ta'veren. And to help find the Horn. . . ."

mæt ən pɛɹɪn ɹoʊɾ ʌp bɪhaɪn lɔɪəl ən pɔzd. mæt lʊkt ə lɪɾəl taɪɝɾ ɝaʊn ði aɪz, bʌɾ ɪz feɪs wɔɹ ə blum ə hɛlθ.

Mat and Perrin rode up behind Loial and paused. Mat looked a little tired around the eyes, but his face wore a bloom of health.

"mæt," ɹænd sɛd, "aɪm sɑɹi fəɹ wʌɾ aɪ sɛd. pɛɹɪn, aɪ dɪdn min ɪt. aɪ wɑz biɪŋ stupəd."

"Mat," Rand said, "I'm sorry for what I said. Perrin, I didn't mean it. I was being stupid."

mæt oʊnli ɡlænst ət hɪm, ðən ʃʊk ɪz hɛɾ ən maʊð sʌmθɪŋ tə pɛɹɪn ðət ɹænd kəd nɑt hɪɹ. mæt hæɾ oʊnli hɪz baʊ ən kwɪvɝ, bʌt pɛɹɪn ɔlsoʊ wɔɹ ɪz æks əɾ ɪz bɛlt, wɪð ɪts bɪɡ hæf-mun bleɪd bæləns baɪ ə θɪk spaɪk.

Mat only glanced at him, then shook his head and mouthed something to Perrin that Rand could not hear. Mat had only his bow and quiver, but Perrin also wore his axe at his belt, with its big half-moon blade balanced by a thick spike.

"mæt? pɛɹɪn? ɹɪli, aɪ dɪdnt - " ðeɪ ɹoʊɾ ɑn təwɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹ.

"Mat? Perrin? Really, I didn't - " They rode on toward Ingtar.

"ðæɾ ɪz nɑɾ ə koʊt fəɹ tʃɹævlɪŋ, ɹænd," lɔɪəl sɛd.

"That is not a coat for traveling, Rand," Loial said.

ɹænd ɡlæns daʊn ət ðə ɡoʊldən θɔɹnz klaɪmɪŋ ɪz kɹɪmzən sliv ən ɡɹɪməst. smɔl wʌndɝ mæt ən pɛɹɪn stɪl θɪŋk aɪm pʊɾɪŋ ɑn ɛɹz. ɑn ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə hɪz ɹum i hæd faʊn ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɔlɹɛɾi pækt ən sɛn ɑn. ɔl ə ðə pleɪn koʊts i hæd bɪn ɡɪvən wɝ ɑn ðə pækhɔɹsɪz, soʊ ðə sɝvəns sɛd; ɛvɹi koʊt lɛft ɪn ðə wɔɹdʒɹoʊb wɑz ət list əz ɔɹneɪɾ əz ðə wʌn i wɔɹ. hɪz sæɾəlbæɡz hɛl nʌθɪŋ ɪn ðə weɪ ʌv kloʊðz bʌɾ ə fju ʃɝts, səm wʊl stɑkɪŋz, ən ə spɛɹ pɛɹ ə bɹitʃɪz. ət list i hæd ɹimuv ðə ɡoʊldən kɔɹd fɹəm ɪz sliv, ðoʊ hi hæd ðə ɹɛɾ iɡəl pɪn ɪn ɪz pɑkət. læn hæd mɛn ɪt fəɹ ə ɡɪft, æftɝ ɔl.

Rand glanced down at the golden thorns climbing his crimson sleeve and grimaced. Small wonder Mat and Perrin still think I'm putting on airs. On returning to his room he had found everything already packed and sent on. All of the plain coats he had been given were on the packhorses, so the servants said; every coat left in the wardrobe was at least as ornate as the one he wore. His saddlebags held nothing in the way of clothes but a few shirts, some wool stockings, and a spare pair of breeches. At least he had removed the golden cord from his sleeve, though he had the red eagle pin in his pocket. Lan had meant it for a gift, after all.

"aɪl tʃeɪnʒ wən wi stɑp tənaɪt," hi mʌɾɝd. hi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. "lɔɪəl, aɪ sɛd θɪŋz tə jə aɪ ʃəd nɑt hæv, ən aɪ hoʊp jəl fɝɡɪv mi. juv ɛvɹi ɹaɪt tə hoʊld əm əɡɛns mi, bʌɾ aɪ hoʊp jə woʊnt."

"I'll change when we stop tonight," he muttered. He took a deep breath. "Loial, I said things to you I should not have, and I hope you'll forgive me. You have every right to hold them against me, but I hope you won't."

lɔɪəl ɡɹɪnd, ən ɪz ɪɹz stʊɾ ʌp. hi muvd ɪz hɔɹs kloʊsɝ. "aɪ seɪ θɪŋz aɪ ʃəd nɑɾ ɔl ðə taɪm. ði ɛldɝz ɔlweɪz sɛɾ aɪ spoʊk ən aʊɝ bɪfɔɹ aɪ θɔt."

Loial grinned, and his ears stood up. He moved his horse closer. "I say things I should not all the time. The Elders always said I spoke an hour before I thought."

sʌɾənli læn wɑz ət ɹændz stɝəp, ɪn ɪz ɡɹeɪ-ɡɹin skeɪld ɑɹmɝ ðət wəd meɪk ɪm ɔl bʌt dɪsəpɪɹ ɪn fɔɹəst əɹ dɑɹknəs. "aɪ nid tə tɔk tə ju, ʃifɝɾɝ." hi lʊkt ət lɔɪəl. "əloʊn, ɪf jə pliz, bɪldɝ." lɔɪəl nɑɾəd ən muvd ɪz bɪɡ hɔɹs əweɪ.

Suddenly Lan was at Rand's stirrup, in his gray-green scaled armor that would make him all but disappear in forest or darkness. "I need to talk to you, sheepherder." He looked at Loial. "Alone, if you please, Builder." Loial nodded and moved his big horse away.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɪf aɪ ʃəd lɪsən tə ju," ɹænd toʊl ðə wɔɹɾɝ. "ðiz fænsi kloʊðz, ən ɔl ðoʊz θɪŋz jə toʊl mi, ðeɪ dɪdn hɛlp mʌtʃ."

"I don't know if I should listen to you," Rand told the Warder. "These fancy clothes, and all those things you told me, they didn't help much."

"wɛn jə kænt wɪn ə bɪɡ vɪktɝi, ʃifɝɾɝ, lɝn tə sɛɾəl fəɹ ðə smɔl wʌnz. ɪf jə meɪɾ əm θɪŋk ə jə əz sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ ðən ə fɑɹmbɔɪ hul bi izi tə hændəl, ðən jə wʌn ə smɔl vɪktɝi. naʊ bi kwaɪəɾ ən lɪsən. aɪv oʊnli taɪm fəɹ wʌn læs lɛsən, ðə hɑɹɾəst. ʃiðɪŋ ðə sɔɹd."

"When you can't win a big victory, sheepherder, learn to settle for the small ones. If you made them think of you as something more than a farmboy who'll be easy to handle, then you won a small victory. Now be quiet and listen. I've only time for one last lesson, the hardest. Sheathing the Sword."

"juv spɛn ən aʊɝ ɛvɹi mɔɹnɪŋ meɪkɪŋ mi də nʌθɪŋ bʌt dʒɹɔ ðɪs blʌɾi sɔɹɾ ən pʊɾ ɪt bæk ɪn ðə skæbɝd. stændɪŋ, sɪɾɪŋ, laɪɪŋ daʊn. aɪ θɪŋk aɪ kən mænədʒ tə ɡɛɾ ɪt bæk ɪn ðə ʃiθ wɪθaʊt kʌɾɪŋ maɪsɛlf."

"You've spent an hour every morning making me do nothing but draw this bloody sword and put it back in the scabbard. Standing, sitting, lying down. I think I can manage to get it back in the sheath without cutting myself."

"aɪ sɛd lɪsən, ʃifɝɾɝ," ðə wɔɹɾɝ ɡɹaʊld. "ðɛɹ wɪl kʌm ə taɪm wən jə mʌst ətʃiv ə ɡoʊl əɾ ɔl kɑsts. ɪt meɪ kʌm ɪn ətæk əɹ ɪn dɪfɛns. ən ði oʊnli weɪ wɪl bi tə əlaʊ ðə sɔɹd tə bi ʃiðd ɪn jəɹ oʊn bɑɾi."

"I said listen, sheepherder," the Warder growled. "There will come a time when you must achieve a goal at all costs. It may come in attack or in defense. And the only way will be to allow the sword to be sheathed in your own body."

"ðæts kɹeɪzi," ɹænd sɛd. "waɪ wəɾ aɪ ɛvɝ - ?"

"That's crazy," Rand said. "Why would I ever - ?"

ðə wɔɹɾɝ kʌɾ ɪm ɔf. "ju wɪl noʊ wən ɪt kʌmz, ʃifɝɾɝ, wən ðə pɹaɪs ɪz wɝθ ðə ɡeɪn, ən ðəɹ ɪz noʊ ʌðɝ tʃɔɪs lɛf tə ju. ðəɾ ɪz kɔld ʃiðɪŋ ðə sɔɹd. ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɪt."

The Warder cut him off. "You will know when it comes, sheepherder, when the price is worth the gain, and there is no other choice left to you. That is called Sheathing the Sword. Remember it."

ði æmɪɝlɪn əpɪɹd, stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə kɹaʊɾəd kɔɹtʃjɑɹd wɪð lin ən əɹ stæf, ən lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ əɾ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. ivən ɪn ə ɡɹin vɛlvət koʊt, ðə lɔɹɾ ə fæl dæɹə dɪd nɑt lʊk aʊɾ ə pleɪs əmʌŋ soʊ mɛni ɑɹmɝd mɛn. ðəɹ wɑz stɪl noʊ saɪn ə ði ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ. əz ðeɪ wɛn baɪ, ɹænd kɑt pɑɹɾ ə ðɛɹ kɑnvɝseɪʃən.

The Amyrlin appeared, striding across the crowded courtyard with Leane and her staff, and Lord Agelmar at her shoulder. Even in a green velvet coat, the Lord of Fal Dara did not look out of place among so many armored men. There was still no sign of the other Aes Sedai. As they went by, Rand caught part of their conversation.

"bʌt, mʌðɝ," eɪɡəlmɝ wɑz pɹətɛstɪŋ, "juv hæd noʊ taɪm tə ɹɛs fɹəm ðə dʒɝni hɪɹ. steɪ ət list ə fju deɪz mɔɹ. aɪ pɹɑməs jə ə fis tənaɪt sətʃ əz jə kəd hɑɹdli ɡɛɾ ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn."

"But, Mother," Agelmar was protesting, "you've had no time to rest from the journey here. Stay at least a few days more. I promise you a feast tonight such as you could hardly get in Tar Valon."

ði æmɪɝlɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd wɪθaʊt bɹeɪkɪŋ stʃɹaɪd. "aɪ kænɑt, eɪɡəlmɝ. jə noʊ aɪ wəɾ ɪf aɪ kʊd. aɪ hæd nɛvɝ plæn tə ɹɪmeɪn lɔŋ, ən mæɾɝz ɝdʒənli ɹikwaɪɝ maɪ pɹɛzəns ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ. aɪ ʃəd bi ðəɹ naʊ."

The Amyrlin shook her head without breaking stride. "I cannot, Agelmar. You know I would if I could. I had never planned to remain long, and matters urgently require my presence in the White Tower. I should be there now."

"mʌðɝ, ɪt ʃeɪmz mi ðət jə kʌm wʌn deɪ ən liv ðə nɛkst. aɪ swɛɹ tə ju, ðəɹ wɪl bi noʊ ɹɛpətɪʃən ə læs naɪt. aɪ hæv tʃɹɪpəl ðə ɡɑɹɾ ɑn ðə sɪɾi ɡeɪts əz wɛl əz ðə kip. aɪ hæv tʌmblɝz ɪn fɹəm ðə taʊn, ən ə bɑɹd kʌmɪŋ fɹəm mɔs ʃɪɹɛɹ. waɪ, kɪŋ isɑɹ wɪl bi ɑn ɪz weɪ fɹəm fæl mɝæn. aɪ sɛnt wɝɾ əz sun æz. . . ."

"Mother, it shames me that you come one day and leave the next. I swear to you, there will be no repetition of last night. I have tripled the guard on the city gates as well as the keep. I have tumblers in from the town, and a bard coming from Mos Shirare. Why, King Easar will be on his way from Fal Moran. I sent word as soon as. . . ."

ðɛɹ vɔɪsəz feɪɾəd əz ðeɪ kɹɔs ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd, swɑloʊɾ ʌp baɪ ðə dɪn ə pɹɛpɝeɪʃən. ði æmɪɝlɪn nɛvɝ əz mʌtʃ əz ɡlænst ɪn ɹændz dɝɛkʃən.

Their voices faded as they crossed the courtyard, swallowed up by the din of preparation. The Amyrlin never as much as glanced in Rand's direction.

wən ɹænd lʊk daʊn, ðə wɔɹɾɝ wɑz ɡɔn, ən noʊwɛɹ tə bi sin. lɔɪəl bɹɔɾ ɪz hɔɹsbæk tə ɹændz saɪd. "ðæɾ ɪz ə hɑɹd mæn tə kætʃ ən hoʊld, ɪzən hi, ɹænd? hiz nɑt hɪɹ, ðən hiz hɪɹ, ðən hiz ɡɔn, ən jə doʊn si hɪm kʌmɪŋ əɹ ɡoʊɪŋ."

When Rand looked down, the Warder was gone, and nowhere to be seen. Loial brought his horseback to Rand's side. "That is a hard man to catch and hold, isn't he, Rand? He's not here, then he's here, then he's gone, and you don't see him coming or going."

ʃiðɪŋ ðə sɔɹd. ɹænd ʃɪvɝd. wɔɹɾɝz mʌst ɔl bi kɹeɪzi.

Sheathing the Sword. Rand shivered. Warders must all be crazy.

ðə wɔɹɾɝ ði æmɪɝlɪn wɑz spikɪŋ tə sʌɾənli spɹæŋ ɪndə hɪz sæɾəl. hi wɑz əɾ ə dɛd ɡæləp bɪfɔɹ i ɹitʃt ðə waɪd-stændɪŋ ɡeɪts. ʃi stʊd wɑtʃɪŋ ɪm ɡoʊ, ən əɹ stæns sim tə ɝdʒ ɪm tə ɡoʊ fæstɝ.

The Warder the Amyrlin was speaking to suddenly sprang into his saddle. He was at a dead gallop before he reached the wide-standing gates. She stood watching him go, and her stance seemed to urge him to go faster.

"wɛɹ ɪz i hɛɾəd ɪn sətʃ ə hɝi?" ɹænd wʌndɝɾ əlaʊd.

"Where is he headed in such a hurry?" Rand wondered aloud.

"aɪ hɝd," lɔɪəl sɛd, "ðæt ʃi wɑz sɛndɪŋ sʌmwʌn aʊt tədeɪ, ɔl ðə weɪ tə ɑɹæd dumən. ðəɹ ɪz wɝɾ ə səm sɔɹɾ ə tʃɹʌbəl ɑn ɑlməθ pleɪn, ən ði æmɪɝlɪn sit wɑns tə noʊ ɪɡzækli wʌt. wʌɾ aɪ doʊn ʌndɝstæn ɪz, waɪ naʊ? fɹəm wʌɾ aɪ hɪɹ, ðə ɹumɝz ə ðɪs tʃɹʌbəl keɪm fɹəm tɑɹ vəlɑn wɪð ði ɛɛs sədaɪ."

"I heard," Loial said, "that she was sending someone out today, all the way to Arad Doman. There is word of some sort of trouble on Almoth Plain, and the Amyrlin Seat wants to know exactly what. What I don't understand is, why now? From what I hear, the rumors of this trouble came from Tar Valon with the Aes Sedai."

ɹænd fɛl koʊld. ɛɡwinz fɑðɝ hæɾ ə bɪɡ mæp bæk ət hoʊm, ə mæp ɹænd hæd pɔɹɾ oʊvɝ mɔɹ ðən wʌns, dʒɹimɪŋ bɪfɔɹ i faʊn aʊt wʌt ðə dʒɹimz wɝ laɪk wən ðeɪ keɪm tʃɹu. ɪt wɑz oʊld, ðət mæp, ʃoʊɪŋ səm lænz ən neɪʃənz ðə mɝtʃəns fɹəm aʊtsaɪd sɛd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɪɡzɪstəd, bʌɾ ɑlməθ pleɪn wɑz mɑɹkt, bʌɾɪŋ əɡɛns toʊmən hɛd. wɪl miɾ əɡɛn ɑn toʊmən hɛd. ɪt wɑz ɔl ðə weɪ əkɹɔs ðə wɝld i nu, ɑn ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən. "ɪɾ əz nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ʌs," hi wɪspɝd. "nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð mi."

Rand felt cold. Egwene's father had a big map back at home, a map Rand had pored over more than once, dreaming before he found out what the dreams were like when they came true. It was old, that map, showing some lands and nations the merchants from outside said no longer existed, but Almoth Plain was marked, butting against Toman Head. We will meet again on Toman Head. It was all the way across the world he knew, on the Aryth Ocean. "It has nothing to do with us," he whispered. "Nothing to do with me."

lɔɪəl əpɪɹd nɑt tə hæv hɝd. ɹʌbɪŋ ðə saɪɾ ə hɪz noʊz wɪð ə fɪŋɡɝ laɪk ə sɔsədʒ, ði oʊɡiɝ wɑz stɪl piɹɪŋ ət ðə ɡeɪt wɛɹ ðə wɔɹɾɝ hæd vænɪʃt. "ɪf ʃi wɑntəd tə noʊ, waɪ nɑt sɛn sʌmwʌn bɪfɔɹ ʃi lɛf tɑɹ vəlɑn? bʌt jə hjumənz ɑɹ ɔlweɪz sʌɾən ən ɪksaɪɾəbəl, ɔlweɪz dʒʌmpɪŋ ɝaʊn ən ʃaʊɾɪŋ." hɪz ɪɹz stɪfənd wɪð ɪmbɛɹəsmənt. "aɪ æm sɑɹi, ɹænd. jə si wʌɾ aɪ min əbaʊt spikɪŋ bɪfɔɹ aɪ θɪŋk. aɪm ɹæʃ ən ɪksaɪɾəbəl səmtaɪmz maɪsɛlf, əz jə noʊ."

Loial appeared not to have heard. Rubbing the side of his nose with a finger like a sausage, the Ogier was still peering at the gate where the Warder had vanished. "If she wanted to know, why not send someone before she left Tar Valon? But you humans are always sudden and excitable, always jumping around and shouting." His ears stiffened with embarrassment. "I am sorry, Rand. You see what I mean about speaking before I think. I'm rash and excitable sometimes myself, as you know."

ɹænd læft. ɪt wɑz ə wik læf, bʌɾ ɪt fɛlt ɡʊd tə hæv sʌmθɪŋ tə læf æt. "meɪbi ɪf wi lɪvd əz lɔŋ əz jə oʊɡiɝ, wid bi mɔɹ sɛɾəld." lɔɪəl wɑz naɪnti jɪɹz oʊld; baɪ oʊɡiɝ stændɝdz, nɑɾ oʊld ɪnʌf baɪ tɛn jɪɹz tə bi aʊtsaɪd ðə stɛɾɪŋ əloʊn. ðəɾ i hæd ɡɔn ɛniweɪ wɑz pɹuf, hi meɪnteɪnd, ʌv ɪz ɹæʃnəs. ɪf lɔɪəl wɑz ən ɪksaɪɾəbəl oʊɡiɝ, ɹænd θɔt moʊst ə ðɛm mʌs bi meɪɾ ə stoʊn.

Rand laughed. It was a weak laugh, but it felt good to have something to laugh at. "Maybe if we lived as long as you Ogier, we'd be more settled." Loial was ninety years old; by Ogier standards, not old enough by ten years to be outside the stedding alone. That he had gone anyway was proof, he maintained, of his rashness. If Loial was an excitable Ogier, Rand thought most of them must be made of stone.

"pɝhæps soʊ," lɔɪəl mjuzd, "bʌt jə hjumənz də soʊ mʌtʃ wɪð jəɹ laɪvz. wi də nʌθɪŋ bʌt hʌɾəl ɪn əɹ stɛɾɪŋ. plæntɪŋ ðə ɡɹoʊvz, ən ivən ðə bɪldɪŋ, wɝ ɔl dʌn bɪfɔɹ ðə lɔŋ ɛɡzaɪl ɛndəd." ɪt wɑz ðə ɡɹoʊvz lɔɪəl hɛl dɪɹ, nɑt ðə sɪɾiz mɛn ɹɪmɛmbɝd ði oʊɡiɝ fəɹ bɪldɪŋ. ɪt wɑz ðə ɡɹoʊvz, plæntəd tə ɹimaɪn oʊɡiɝ bɪldɝz ə ðə stɛɾɪŋ, ðət lɔɪəl hæd lɛft ɪz hoʊm tə si. "sɪns wi faʊn əɹ weɪ bæk tə ðə stɛɾɪŋ, wi. . . ." hɪz wɝdz tʃɹeɪld ɔf əz ði æmɪɝlɪn əpɹoʊtʃt.

"Perhaps so," Loial mused, "but you humans do so much with your lives. We do nothing but huddle in our stedding. Planting the groves, and even the building, were all done before the Long Exile ended." It was the groves Loial held dear, not the cities men remembered the Ogier for building. It was the groves, planted to remind Ogier Builders of the stedding, that Loial had left his home to see. "Since we found our way back to the stedding, we. . . ." His words trailed off as the Amyrlin approached.

ɪŋtʃɹ ən ði ʌðɝ mɛn ʃɪftəɾ ɪn ðɛɹ sæɾəlz, pɹipɛɹɪŋ tə dɪsmaʊn ən nil, bʌt ʃi moʊʃən əm tə steɪ əz ðeɪ wɝ. lin stʊɾ əɾ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ, ən eɪɡəlmɝ ə peɪs bæk. fɹəm ɪz ɡlʌm feɪs, hi əpɪɹd tə hæv ɡɪvən ʌp tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kənvɪns əɹ tə ɹɪmeɪn lɔŋɡɝ.

Ingtar and the other men shifted in their saddles, preparing to dismount and kneel, but she motioned them to stay as they were. Leane stood at her shoulder, and Agelmar a pace back. From his glum face, he appeared to have given up trying to convince her to remain longer.

ði æmɪɝlɪn lʊkt əɾ əm wʌn baɪ wʌn bɪfɔɹ ʃi spoʊk. hɝ ɡeɪz steɪɾ ɑn ɹænd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ðən ɑn ɛni ʌðɝ.

The Amyrlin looked at them one by one before she spoke. Her gaze stayed on Rand no longer than on any other.

"pis feɪvɝ jəɹ sɔɹd, lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹ," ʃi sɛd faɪnəli. "ɡlɔɹi tə ðə bɪldɝz, lɔɪəl kaɪsɝən."

"Peace favor your sword, Lord Ingtar," she said finally. "Glory to the Builders, Loial Kiseran."

"ju ɑnɝ ʌs, mʌðɝ. meɪ pis feɪvɝ tɑɹ vəlɑn." ɪŋtʃɹ baʊɾ ɪn ɪz sæɾəl, ən ði ʌðɝ ʃaɪnɝənz dɪd, tu.

"You honor us, Mother. May peace favor Tar Valon." Ingtar bowed in his saddle, and the other Shienarans did, too.

"ɔl ɑnɝ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn," lɔɪəl sɛd, boʊɪŋ.

"All honor to Tar Valon," Loial said, bowing.

oʊnli ɹænd, ən ɪz tu fɹɛnz ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə pɑɹɾi, steɪɾ əpɹaɪt. hi wʌndɝd wʌt ʃi hæd sɛd tə ðɛm. linz fɹaʊn tʊk ɪn ɔl θɹi ʌv ðɛm, ən eɪɡəlmɝz aɪz waɪɾənd, bʌt ði æmɪɝlɪn tʊk noʊ noʊɾəs.

Only Rand, and his two friends on the other side of the party, stayed upright. He wondered what she had said to them. Leane's frown took in all three of them, and Agelmar's eyes widened, but the Amyrlin took no notice.

"ju ɹaɪd tə faɪn ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ," ʃi sɛd, "æn ðə hoʊp ə ðə wɝld ɹaɪdz wɪð ju. ðə hɔɹn kænɑt bi lɛft ɪn ðə ɹɔŋ hænz, ɪspɛʃli ɪn dɑɹkfɹɛn hænz. ðoʊz u kʌm tə ænsɝ ɪts kɔl, wɪl kʌm huɛvɝ bloʊz ɪt, ən ðeɪ ɑɹ baʊn tə ðə hɔɹn, nɑt tə ðə laɪt."

"You ride to find the Horn of Valere," she said, "and the hope of the world rides with you. The Horn cannot be left in the wrong hands, especially in Darkfriend hands. Those who come to answer its call, will come whoever blows it, and they are bound to the Horn, not to the Light."

ðəɹ wɑz ə stɝ əmʌŋ ðə lɪsnɪŋ mɛn. ɛvɹiwʌn bɪliv ðət ðoʊz hɪɹoʊz kɔl bæk fɹəm ðə ɡɹeɪv wəd faɪt fəɹ ðə laɪt. ɪf ðeɪ kəd faɪt fəɹ ðə ʃædoʊ, ɪnstɛd. . . .

There was a stir among the listening men. Everyone believed that those heroes called back from the grave would fight for the Light. If they could fight for the Shadow, instead. . . .

ði æmɪɝlɪn wɛn ɑn, bʌt ɹænd wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ lɪsnɪŋ. ðə wɑtʃɝ wɑz bæk. ðə hɛɹ stɝɾ ɑn ðə bæk ə hɪz nɛk. hi pɪɹɾ ʌp ət ðə pækt ɑɹtʃɝz' bælkəniz oʊvɝlʊkɪŋ ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd, ət ðə ɹoʊz ə pipəl dʒæmd əlɔŋ ðə ɡɑɹdwɔks ətɑp ðə wɔlz. sʌmwɛɹ əmʌŋ əm wɑz ðə sɛɾ ʌv aɪz ðət hæd fɑloʊɾ ɪm ənsin. ðə ɡeɪz klʌŋ tə hɪm laɪk dɝɾi ɔɪl. ɪt kæn bi ə feɪd, nɑt hɪɹ. ðən hu? əɹ wʌt? hi twɪstəɾ ɪn ɪz sæɾəl, pʊlɪŋ ɹɛɾ ɝaʊnd, sɝtʃɪŋ. ðə beɪ bɪɡæn tə dæns əɡɛn.

The Amyrlin went on, but Rand was no longer listening. The watcher was back. The hair stirred on the back of his neck. He peered up at the packed archers' balconies overlooking the courtyard, at the rows of people jammed along the guardwalks atop the walls. Somewhere among them was the set of eyes that had followed him unseen. The gaze clung to him like dirty oil. It can't be a Fade, not here. Then who? Or what? He twisted in his saddle, pulling Red around, searching. The bay began to dance again.

sʌɾənli sʌmθɪŋ flæʃt əkɹɔs ɪn fɹʌn ə ɹændz feɪs. ə mæn pæsɪŋ bɪhaɪn ði æmɪɝlɪn kɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ən fɛl, ə blæk-flɛtʃt æɹoʊ dʒʌɾɪŋ fɹəm ɪz saɪd. ði æmɪɝlɪn stʊd kɑmli lʊkɪŋ əɾ ə ɹɛn ɪn əɹ sliv; blʌd sloʊli steɪn ðə ɡɹeɪ sɪlk.

Suddenly something flashed across in front of Rand's face. A man passing behind the Amyrlin cried out and fell, a black-fletched arrow jutting from his side. The Amyrlin stood calmly looking at a rent in her sleeve; blood slowly stained the gray silk.
