ə wʊmən skɹimd, ən əbɹʌpli ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd ɹæŋ wɪð kɹaɪz ən ʃaʊts. ðə pipəl ɑn ðə wɔlz mɪl fjʊɹiəsli, ən ɛvɹi mæn ɪn ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd hæɾ ɪz sɔɹɾ aʊt. ivən ɹænd, hi wɑz sɝpɹaɪz tə ɹilaɪz.

A woman screamed, and abruptly the courtyard rang with cries and shouts. The people on the walls milled furiously, and every man in the courtyard had his sword out. Even Rand, he was surprised to realize.

eɪɡəlmɝ ʃʊk ɪz bleɪɾ ət ðə skaɪ. "faɪn hɪm!" hi ɹɔɹd. "bɹɪŋ ɪm tə mi!" hɪz feɪs wɛn fɹəm ɹɛd tə waɪt wən i sɔ ðə blʌɾ ɑn ði æmɪɝlɪnz sliv. hi fɛl tə hɪz niz, hɛd baʊd. "fɝɡɪv, mʌðɝ. aɪ hæv feɪl jəɹ seɪfti. aɪm əʃeɪmd."

Agelmar shook his blade at the sky. "Find him!" he roared. "Bring him to me!" His face went from red to white when he saw the blood on the Amyrlin's sleeve. He fell to his knees, head bowed. "Forgive, Mother. I have failed your safety. I am ashamed."

"nɑnsɛns, eɪɡəlmɝ," ði æmɪɝlɪn sɛd. "lin, stɑp fʌsɪŋ oʊvɝ mi ən si tə ðət mæn. aɪv kʌt maɪsɛlf wɝs ðən ðɪs mɔɹ ðən wʌns klinɪŋ fɪʃ, ən i nidz hɛlp naʊ. eɪɡəlmɝ, stæn ʌp. stæn ʌp, lɔɹɾ ə fæl dæɹə. juv nɑt feɪl mi, ən juv noʊ ɹizən fəɹ ʃeɪm. læs jɪɹ ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, wɪð maɪ oʊn ɡɑɹdz əɾ ɛvɹi ɡeɪɾ ən wɔɹɾɝz ɔl ɝaʊn mi, ə mæn wɪð ə naɪf keɪm wɪðɪn faɪv stɛps ə mi. eɪ waɪtkloʊk, noʊ daʊt, ðoʊ aɪv noʊ pɹuf. pliz stæn ʌp, əɹ əl bi ʃeɪmd." əz eɪɡəlmɝ sloʊli ɹoʊz, ʃi fɪŋɡɝɾ əɹ slaɪst sliv. "ə pʊɹ ʃɑt fəɹ ə waɪtkloʊk boʊmən, əɹ ivən ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd." hɝ aɪz flɪkɝɾ ʌp tə tʌtʃ ɹænz. "ɪf ɪt wɑz ət mi hi eɪmd." hɝ ɡeɪz wɑz ɡɔn bɪfɔɹ i kəd ɹiɾ ɛniθɪŋ ɑn əɹ feɪs, bʌɾ i sʌɾənli wɑntəd tə dɪsmaʊn ən haɪd.

"Nonsense, Agelmar," the Amyrlin said. "Leane, stop fussing over me and see to that man. I've cut myself worse than this more than once cleaning fish, and he needs help now. Agelmar, stand up. Stand up, Lord of Fal Dara. You have not failed me, and you have no reason for shame. Last year in the White Tower, with my own guards at every gate and Warders all around me, a man with a knife came within five steps of me. A Whitecloak, no doubt, though I've no proof. Please stand up, or I will be shamed." As Agelmar slowly rose, she fingered her sliced sleeve. "A poor shot for a Whitecloak bowman, or even a Darkfriend." Her eyes flickered up to touch Rand's. "If it was at me he aimed." Her gaze was gone before he could read anything on her face, but he suddenly wanted to dismount and hide.

ɪt wɑzn eɪmd ət hɝ, ən ʃi noʊz ɪt.

It wasn't aimed at her, and she knows it.

lin stʃɹeɪɾənd fɹəm wɛɹ ʃi hæd bɪn nilɪŋ. sʌmwʌn hæd leɪɾ ə kloʊk oʊvɝ ðə feɪs ə ðə mæn u hæd teɪkən ði æɹoʊ. "hi ɪz dɛd, mʌðɝ." ʃi saʊndəd taɪɝd. "hi wɑz dɛd wən i stʃɹʌk ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ivən ɪf aɪ hæd bɪn əɾ ɪz saɪd. . . ."

Leane straightened from where she had been kneeling. Someone had laid a cloak over the face of the man who had taken the arrow. "He is dead, Mother." She sounded tired. "He was dead when he struck the ground. Even if I had been at his side. . . ."

"ju dɪd wʌt jə kʊd, dɔɾɝ. dɛθ kænɑt bi hild."

"You did what you could, Daughter. Death cannot be Healed."

eɪɡəlmɝ muv kloʊsɝ. "mʌðɝ, ɪf ðəɹ ɑɹ waɪtkloʊk kɪlɝz əbaʊt, əɹ dɑɹkfɹɛnz, jə mʌst əlaʊ mi tə sɛn mɛn wɪð ju. əz fɑɹ əz ðə ɹɪvɝ, ət list. aɪ kəd nɑt lɪv ɪf hɑɹm keɪm tə jə ɪn ʃaɪnɝ. pliz, ɹɪtɝn tə ðə wɪmənz əpɑɹtməns. əl si ðɛm ɡɑɹɾəd wɪð maɪ laɪf əntɪl jə ɑɹ ɹɛɾi tə tʃɹævəl."

Agelmar moved closer. "Mother, if there are Whitecloak killers about, or Darkfriends, you must allow me to send men with you. As far as the river, at least. I could not live if harm came to you in Shienar. Please, return to the women's apartments. I will see them guarded with my life until you are ready to travel."

"bi əɾ iz," ʃi toʊl hɪm. "ðɪs skɹætʃ wɪl nɑt dɪleɪ mi ə moʊmənt. jɛs, jɛs, əl ɡlædli æksɛp jəɹ mɛn əz fɑɹ əz ðə ɹɪvɝ, ɪf jə ɪnsɪst. bʌɾ əl nɑt lɛt ðɪs dɪleɪ lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹ ə moʊmənt, iðɝ. ɛvɹi hɑɹtbit kaʊns əntɪl ðə hɔɹn ɪz faʊn əɡɛn. jəɹ liv, lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ, tə ɔɹɾɝ jəɹ oʊθmɛn?"

"Be at ease," she told him. "This scratch will not delay me a moment. Yes, yes, I will gladly accept your men as far as the river, if you insist. But I will not let this delay Lord Ingtar a moment, either. Every heartbeat counts until the Horn is found again. Your leave, Lord Agelmar, to order your oathmen?"

hi baʊɾ ɪz hɛɾ ɪn əsɛnt. ət ðət moʊmən i wʊɾə ɡɪvən əɹ fæl dæɹə hæd ʃi æskt.

He bowed his head in assent. At that moment he would have given her Fal Dara had she asked.

ði æmɪɝlɪn tɝn bæk tə ɪŋtʃɹ ən ðə mɛn ɡæðɝd bɪhaɪn hɪm. ʃi dɪd nɑt lʊk ət ɹænd əɡɛn. hi wɑz sɝpɹaɪz tə si hɝ smaɪl sʌɾənli.

The Amyrlin turned back to Ingtar and the men gathered behind him. She did not look at Rand again. He was surprised to see her smile suddenly.

"aɪ weɪdʒɝ ɪljən dʌz nɑt ɡɪv ɪts ɡɹeɪt hʌn ə ðə hɔɹn soʊ ɹaʊzɪŋ ə sɛnd-ɔf," ʃi sɛd. "bʌt jʊɹz ɪz ðə tʃɹu ɡɹeɪt hʌnt. jə ɑɹ fju, soʊ jə meɪ tʃɹævəl kwɪkli, jɛɾ ɪnʌf tə də wʌt jə mʌst. aɪ tʃɑɹdʒ ju, lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹ ə haʊs ʃɪnoʊwə, aɪ tʃɑɹdʒ ɔl ə ju, faɪn ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ, ən lɛt nʌθɪŋ bɑɹ jəɹ weɪ."

"I wager Illian does not give its Great Hunt of the Horn so rousing a send-off," she said. "But yours is the true Great Hunt. You are few, so you may travel quickly, yet enough to do what you must. I charge you, Lord Ingtar of House Shinowa, I charge all of you, find the Horn of Valere, and let nothing bar your way."

ɪŋtʃɹ wɪpt ɪz sɔɹd fɹəm ɪz bæk ən kɪs ðə bleɪd. "baɪ maɪ laɪf ən soʊl, baɪ maɪ haʊs ən ɑnɝ, aɪ swɛɹ ɪt, mʌðɝ."

Ingtar whipped his sword from his back and kissed the blade. "By my life and soul, by my House and honor, I swear it, Mother."

"ðɛn ɹaɪd."

"Then ride."

ɪŋtʃɹ swʌŋ ɪz hɔɹs təwɔɹd ðə ɡeɪt.

Ingtar swung his horse toward the gate.

ɹænd dʌɡ hɪz hilz ɪndə ɹɛdz flæŋks ən ɡæləpt æftɝ ðə kɑləm ɔlɹɛɾi dɪsəpɪɹɪŋ θɹu ðə ɡeɪts.

Rand dug his heels into Red's flanks and galloped after the column already disappearing through the gates.

ʌnəwɛɹ ʌv wʌt hæɾ əkɝd wɪðɪn, ði æmɪɝlɪnz pɪkmɛn ən ɑɹtʃɝz stʊd wɔlɪŋ ə pæθ fɹəm ðə ɡeɪts tə ðə sɪɾi pɹɑpɝ, ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn ɑn ðɛɹ tʃɛsts. hɝ dʒɹʌmɝz ən tʃɹʌmpəɾɝz weɪɾəd nɪɹ ðə ɡeɪts, ɹɛɾi tə fɔl ɪn wən ʃi lɛft. bɪhaɪn ðə ɹoʊz ʌv ɑɹmɝd mɛn, pipəl pæk ðə skwɛɹ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə kip. səm tʃɪɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹz bænɝ, ən ʌðɝz noʊ daʊt θɔt ðɪs wɑz ðə stɑɹɾ ə ði æmɪɝlɪn sits dɪpɑɹtʃɝ. ə swɛlɪŋ ɹɔɹ fɑloʊd ɹænd əkɹɔs ðə skwɛɹ.

Unaware of what had occurred within, the Amyrlin's pikemen and archers stood walling a path from the gates to the city proper, the Flame of Tar Valon on their chests. Her drummers and trumpeters waited near the gates, ready to fall in when she left. Behind the rows of armored men, people packed the square in front of the keep. Some cheered Ingtar's banner, and others no doubt thought this was the start of the Amyrlin Seat's departure. A swelling roar followed Rand across the square.

hi kɑɾ ʌp wɪð ɪŋtʃɹ wɛɹ loʊ-iv haʊsəz ən ʃɑps stʊd tə iðɝ saɪd, ən mɔɹ pipəl θɪkli laɪn ðə stoʊn-peɪv stʃɹit. səm ə ðɛm tʃɪɹd, tu. mæt ən pɛɹɪn hæd bɪn ɹaɪɾɪŋ ət ðə hɛɾ ə ðə kɑləm wɪð ɪŋtʃɹ ən lɔɪəl, bʌt ðə tu ʌv əm fɛl bæk wən ɹænd dʒɔɪn ðɛm. haʊ æm aɪ ɛvɝ gɑnə əpɑlədʒaɪz ɪf ðeɪ woʊn steɪ nɪɹ mi lɔŋ ɪnʌf fəɹ mi tə seɪ ɛniθɪŋ? bɝn mi, hi dʌzn lʊk laɪk hiz daɪɪŋ.

He caught up with Ingtar where low-eaved houses and shops stood to either side, and more people thickly lined the stone-paved street. Some of them cheered, too. Mat and Perrin had been riding at the head of the column with Ingtar and Loial, but the two of them fell back when Rand joined them. How am I ever going to apologize if they won't stay near me long enough for me to say anything? Burn me, he doesn't look like he's dying.

"tʃæŋɡʌ ən naɪdaʊ ɑɹ ɡɔn," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛɾ əbɹʌpli. hi saʊndəd koʊld ən æŋɡɹi, bʌt ʃeɪkən, tu. "wi kaʊntəɾ ɛvɹi hɛɾ ɪn ðə kip, əlaɪv əɹ dɛd, læs naɪɾ ən əɡɛn ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ. ðeɪ ɑɹ ði oʊnli wʌnz nɑɾ əkaʊntəd fɔɹ."

"Changu and Nidao are gone," Ingtar said abruptly. He sounded cold and angry, but shaken, too. "We counted every head in the keep, alive or dead, last night and again this morning. They are the only ones not accounted for."

"tʃæŋɡʌ wɑz ɑn ɡɑɹɾ ɪn ðə dʌnʒən jɛstɝdeɪ," ɹænd sɛd sloʊli.

"Changu was on guard in the dungeon yesterday," Rand said slowly.

"ænd naɪdaʊ. ðeɪ hæd ðə sɛkənd wɑtʃ. ðeɪ ɔlweɪz steɪd təɡɛðɝ, ivən ɪf ðeɪ hæd tə tʃɹeɪɾ əɹ də ɛkstʃɹə duɾi fəɹ ɪt. ðeɪ wɝ nɑɾ ɑn ɡɑɹd wən ɪt hæpənd, bʌt. . . . ðeɪ fɔɾ ət tɑɹwɪnz ɡæp, ə mʌnθ ɡɔn, ən seɪv lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ wən ɪz hɔɹs wɛn daʊn wɪð tʃɹɑləks ɔl ɝaʊn hɪm. naʊ ðɪs. dɑɹkfɹɛnz." hi dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ. "ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪz bɹeɪkɪŋ əpɑɹt."

"And Nidao. They had the second watch. They always stayed together, even if they had to trade or do extra duty for it. They were not on guard when it happened, but. . . . They fought at Tarwin's Gap, a month gone, and saved Lord Agelmar when his horse went down with Trollocs all around him. Now this. Darkfriends." He drew a deep breath. "Everything is breaking apart."

ə mæn ɑn hɔɹsbæk fɔɹst ɪz weɪ θɹu ðə θɹɔŋ laɪnɪŋ ðə stʃɹiɾ ən dʒɔɪn ɪn bɪhaɪn ɪŋtʃɹ. hi wɑz ə taʊnzmən, baɪ hɪz kloʊðz, lin, wɪð ə laɪn feɪs ən ɡɹeɪɪŋ hɛɹ kʌt lɔŋ. ə bʌndəl ən wɔɾɝbətəlz wɝ læʃt bɪhaɪn ɪz sæɾəl, ən ə ʃɔɹt-bleɪɾɪd sɔɹɾ ən ə nɑtʃt sɔɹd-bɹeɪkɝ hʌŋ əɾ ɪz bɛlt, əlɔŋ wɪð ə kʌdʒəl.

A man on horseback forced his way through the throng lining the street and joined in behind Ingtar. He was a townsman, by his clothes, lean, with a lined face and graying hair cut long. A bundle and waterbottles were lashed behind his saddle, and a short-bladed sword and a notched sword-breaker hung at his belt, along with a cudgel.

ɪŋtʃɹ noʊɾəst ɹændz ɡlænsɪz. "ðɪs ɪz hʊɹɪn, əɹ snɪfɝ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid tə lɛt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ noʊ əbaʊt hɪm. nɑt ðət wʌɾ i dʌz ɪz ɹɔŋ, jə ʌndɝstænd. ðə kɪŋ kips ə snɪfɝ ɪn fæl mɝæn, ən ðɛɹz ənʌðɝ ɪn ɑŋkɝ deɪl. ɪts dʒʌs ðəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛldəm laɪk wʌt ðeɪ də nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd, ən wɪð ɪm biɪŋ ə mæn. . . . ɪts nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðə paʊɝ, ʌv kɔɹs. ɑə! jə tɛl hɪm, hʊɹɪn."

Ingtar noticed Rand's glances. "This is Hurin, our sniffer. There was no need to let the Aes Sedai know about him. Not that what he does is wrong, you understand. The King keeps a sniffer in Fal Moran, and there's another in Ankor Dail. It's just that Aes Sedai seldom like what they do not understand, and with him being a man. . . . It's nothing to do with the Power, of course. Aaaah! You tell him, Hurin."

"jɛs, lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹ," ðə mæn sɛd. hi baʊd loʊ tə ɹænd fɹəm ɪz sæɾəl. "ɑnɝ tə sɝv, maɪ lɔɹd."

"Yes, Lord Ingtar," the man said. He bowed low to Rand from his saddle. "Honor to serve, my Lord."

"kɔl mi ɹænd." ɹænd stʌk aʊɾ ɪz hænd, ən æftɝ ə moʊmən hʊɹɪn ɡɹɪn ən tʊk ɪt.

"Call me Rand." Rand stuck out his hand, and after a moment Hurin grinned and took it.

"æz jə wɪʃ, maɪ lɔɹd ɹænd. lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹ ən lɔɹd keɪdʒɪn doʊn maɪn ə mænz weɪz - ən lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ, ʌv kɔɹs - bʌt ðeɪ seɪ ɪn ðə taʊn jəɹ ən aʊtlæn pɹɪns fɹəm ðə saʊθ, ən səm aʊtlæn lɔɹdz ɑɹ stʃɹɪk fəɹ ɛvɹi mæn ɪn ɪz pleɪs."

"As you wish, my Lord Rand. Lord Ingtar and Lord Kajin don't mind a man's ways - and Lord Agelmar, of course - but they say in the town you're an outland prince from the south, and some outland lords are strict for every man in his place."

"aɪm nɑɾ ə lɔɹd." ət list əl ɡɛɾ əweɪ fɹəm ðæt, naʊ. "dʒʌst ɹænd."

"I'm not a lord." At least I'll get away from that, now. "Just Rand."

hʊɹɪn blɪŋkt. "æz jə wɪʃ, maɪ lɔɹ - ɑ - ɹænd. ɪm ə snɪfɝ, jə si. bɪn wʌn fɔɹ jɪɹz ðɪs sʌndeɪ. aɪ nɛvɝ hɝɾ ə sətʃ ə θɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ðɛn, bʌɾ aɪ hɪɹ ðɛɹz ə fju ʌðɝz laɪk mi. ɪt stɑɹɾəd sloʊ, kætʃɪŋ bæd smɛlz wɛɹ noʊbɑdi ɛls smɛld ɛniθɪŋ, ən ɪt ɡɹu. tʊk ə hoʊl jɪɹ bɪfɔɹ aɪ ɹilaɪzd wʌɾ ɪt wɑz. aɪ kəd smɛl vaɪələns, ðə kɪlɪŋ ən ðə hɝɾɪŋ. smɛl wɛɹ ɪt hæpənd. smɛl ðə tʃɹeɪl ə ðoʊz u dɪɾ ɪt. ɛvɹi tʃɹeɪlz dɪfɹənt, soʊ ðɛɹz noʊ tʃæns ə mɪksɪŋ əm ʌp. lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹ hɝɾ ʌv ɪt, ən tʊk mi ɪn ɪz sɝvəs, tə sɝv ðə kɪŋz dʒʌstəs."

Hurin blinked. "As you wish, my Lor - ah - Rand. I'm a sniffer, you see. Been one four years this Sunday. I never heard of such a thing before then, but I hear there's a few others like me. It started slow, catching bad smells where nobody else smelled anything, and it grew. Took a whole year before I realized what it was. I could smell violence, the killing and the hurting. Smell where it happened. Smell the trail of those who did it. Every trail's different, so there's no chance of mixing them up. Lord Ingtar heard of it, and took me in his service, to serve the King's justice."

"ju kən smɛl vaɪələns?" ɹænd sɛd. hi kəd nɑt hɛlp lʊkɪŋ ət ðə mænz noʊz. ɪt wɑz ən ɔɹɾənɛɹi noʊz, nɑt lɑɹdʒ, nɑt smɔl. "ju min jə kən ɹɪli fɑloʊ sʌmbɑɾi hu, seɪ, kɪld ənʌðɝ mæn? baɪ smɛl?"

"You can smell violence?" Rand said. He could not help looking at the man's nose. It was an ordinary nose, not large, not small. "You mean you can really follow somebody who, say, killed another man? By smell?"

"aɪ kən ðæt, maɪ lɔɹ - ɑ - ɹænd. ɪt feɪdz wɪð taɪm, bʌt ðə wɝs ðə vaɪələns, ðə lɔŋɡɝ ɪt læsts. eɪi, aɪ kən smɛl ə bæɾəlfild tɛn jɪɹz oʊld, ðoʊ ðə tʃɹeɪlz ə ðə mɛn u wɝ ðəɹ ɑɹ ɡɔn. ʌp nɪɹ ðə blaɪt, ðə tʃɹeɪlz ə ðə tʃɹɑləks ɔlmoʊs nɛvɝ feɪd. nɑt mʌtʃ tə ə tʃɹɑlɑk bʌt kɪlɪŋ ən hɝɾɪŋ. ə faɪɾ ɪn ə tævɝn, ðoʊ, wɪð meɪbi ə bɹoʊkən ɑɹm . . . ðət smɛlz ɡɔn ɪn aʊɝz."

"I can that, my Lor - ah - Rand. It fades with time, but the worse the violence, the longer it lasts. Aiie, I can smell a battlefield ten years old, though the trails of the men who were there are gone. Up near the Blight, the trails of the Trollocs almost never fade. Not much to a Trolloc but killing and hurting. A fight in a tavern, though, with maybe a broken arm . . . that smell's gone in hours."

"aɪ kən si wɛɹ jə wʊdnt wɑn ɛɛs sədaɪ tə faɪn aʊt."

"I can see where you wouldn't want Aes Sedai to find out."

"ɑ, lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹ wɑz ɹaɪɾ əbaʊt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin əm - ɑ - ɹænd. ðəɹ wɑz wʌn ɪn kɛɹhin wʌns - bɹaʊn ədʒɑ, bʌɾ aɪ swɛɹ aɪ θɔt ʃi wɑz ɹɛd bɪfɔɹ ʃi lemi ɡoʊ - ʃi kɛp mi ə mʌnθ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪn aʊt haʊ aɪ də ɪt. ʃi dɪdn laɪk nɑt noʊɪŋ. ʃi kɛp mʌɾɝɪŋ, 'ɪz ɪɾ oʊl kʌm əɡɛn, əɹ nu?' ən stɛɹɪŋ ət mi əntɪl jə wʊɾə θɔɾ aɪ wɑz juzɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ɔlmoʊs hæd mi daʊɾɪŋ maɪsɛlf. bʌɾ aɪ hævənt ɡɔn mæd, ən aɪ doʊn də ɛniθɪŋ. aɪ dʒʌst smɛl ɪt."

"Ah, Lord Ingtar was right about the Aes Sedai, the Light illumine them - ah - Rand. There was one in Cairhien once - Brown Ajah, but I swear I thought she was Red before she let me go - she kept me a month trying to find out how I do it. She didn't like not knowing. She kept muttering, 'Is it old come again, or new?' and staring at me until you would have thought I was using the One Power. Almost had me doubting myself. But I haven't gone mad, and I don't do anything. I just smell it."

ɹænd kəd nɑt hɛlp ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ mɔɪɹeɪn. oʊl bæɹiɝz wikən. ðəɹ ɪz sʌmθɪŋ ə dɪsəluʃən ən tʃeɪnʒ əbaʊɾ əɹ taɪm. oʊl θɪŋz wɔk əɡɛn, ən nu θɪŋz ɑɹ bɔɹn. wi meɪ lɪv tə si ði ɛn ʌv ən eɪdʒ. hi ʃɪvɝd. "soʊ wɪl tʃɹæk ðoʊz u tʊk ðə hɔɹn wɪð jəɹ noʊz."

Rand could not help remembering Moiraine. Old barriers weaken. There is something of dissolution and change about our time. Old things walk again, and new things are born. We may live to see the end of an Age. He shivered. "So we'll track those who took the Horn with your nose."

ɪŋtʃɹ nɑɾəd. hʊɹɪn ɡɹɪn pɹaʊdli, ən sɛd, "wi wɪl ðət - ɑ - ɹænd. aɪ fɑloʊɾ ə mɝɾɝɝ tə kɛɹhin, wʌns, ən ənʌðɝ ɔl ðə weɪ tə mɛɹədɑn, tə bɹɪŋ əm bæk fəɹ ðə kɪŋz dʒʌstəs." hɪz ɡɹɪn feɪɾəd, ən i lʊk tʃɹʌbəld. "ðɪs ɪz ðə wɝst ɛvɝ, ðoʊ. mɝɾɝ smɛlz bæd, ən ðə tʃɹeɪl ʌv ə mɝɾɝɝ stɪŋks wɪð ɪt, bʌt ðɪs. . . ." hɪz noʊz ɹɪŋkəld. "ðɛɹ wɝ mɛn ɪn ɪt læs naɪt. dɑɹkfɹɛnz, mʌs bi, bʌt jə kæn tɛl ə dɑɹkfɹɛn baɪ smɛl. wʌɾ əl fɑloʊ ɪz ðə tʃɹɑləks, ən ðə hæfmən. ən sʌmθɪŋ ivən wɝs." hi tʃɹeɪld ɔf, fɹaʊnɪŋ ən mʌɾɝɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf, bʌt ɹænd kəd hɪɹ ɪt. "sʌmθɪŋ ivən wɝs, ðə laɪt hɛlp mi."

Ingtar nodded. Hurin grinned proudly, and said, "We will that - ah - Rand. I followed a murderer to Cairhien, once, and another all the way to Maradon, to bring them back for the King's justice." His grin faded, and he looked troubled. "This is the worst ever, though. Murder smells bad, and the trail of a murderer stinks with it, but this. . . ." His nose wrinkled. "There were men in it last night. Darkfriends, must be, but you can't tell a Darkfriend by smell. What I'll follow is the Trollocs, and the Halfmen. And something even worse." He trailed off, frowning and muttering to himself, but Rand could hear it. "Something even worse, the Light help me."

ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə sɪɾi ɡeɪts, ən dʒʌs bɪɑn ðə wɔlz hʊɹɪn lɪftəɾ ɪz feɪs tə ðə bɹiz. hɪz nɑstʃɹəlz flɛɹd, ðən i ɡeɪv ə snɔɹɾ ə dɪsɡʌst. "ðæt weɪ, maɪ lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹ." hi pɔɪntəd saʊθ.

They reached the city gates, and just beyond the walls Hurin lifted his face to the breeze. His nostrils flared, then he gave a snort of disgust. "That way, my Lord Ingtar." He pointed south.

ɪŋtʃɹ lʊk sɝpɹaɪzd. "nɑt təwɔɹd ðə blaɪt?"

Ingtar looked surprised. "Not toward the Blight?"

"noʊ, lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹ. fɔ!" hʊɹɪn waɪpt ɪz maʊθ ɑn ɪz sliv. "aɪ kən ɔlmoʊs teɪs ðɛm. saʊθ, ðeɪ wɛnt."

"No, Lord Ingtar. Faugh!" Hurin wiped his mouth on his sleeve. "I can almost taste them. South, they went."

"ʃi wɑz ɹaɪt, ðɛn, ði æmɪɝlɪn sit," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd sloʊli. "ə ɡɹeɪɾ ən waɪz wʊmən, hu dɪzɝvz bɛɾɝ ðən mi tə sɝv hɝ. teɪk ðə tʃɹeɪl, hʊɹɪn."

"She was right, then, the Amyrlin Seat," Ingtar said slowly. "A great and wise woman, who deserves better than me to serve her. Take the trail, Hurin."

ɹænd tɝn ən pɪɹd bæk θɹu ðə ɡeɪts, ʌp ðə stʃɹit tə ðə kip. hi hoʊpt ɛɡwin wɑz ɔl ɹaɪt. nɪneɪiv wɪl lʊk æftɝ hɝ. meɪbi ɪts bɛɾɝ ðɪs weɪ, laɪk ə klin kʌt, tu kwɪk tə hɝt tɪl æftɝ ɪts dʌn.

Rand turned and peered back through the gates, up the street to the keep. He hoped Egwene was all right. Nynaeve will look after her. Maybe it's better this way, like a clean cut, too quick to hurt till after it's done.

hi ɹoʊɾ æftɝ ɪŋtʃɹ ən ðə ɡɹeɪ aʊl bænɝ, saʊθ. ðə wɪnd wɑz meɪkɪŋ ʌp, ən koʊld əɡɛnst ɪz bæk dɪspaɪt ðə sʌn. hi θɔɾ i hɝd læftɝ ɪn ɪt, feɪn ən mɑkɪŋ.

He rode after Ingtar and the Gray Owl banner, south. The wind was making up, and cold against his back despite the sun. He thought he heard laughter in it, faint and mocking.

ðə wæksɪŋ mun lɪt ðə hjuməd, naɪt-dɑɹk stʃɹits ʌv ɪljən, wɪtʃ stɪl ɹæŋ wɪð sɛləbɹeɪʃən lɛft oʊvɝ fɹəm deɪlaɪt. ɪn oʊnli ə fju mɔɹ deɪz, ðə ɡɹeɪt hʌn ə ðə hɔɹn wəd bi sɛn fɔɹθ wɪð pɑmp ən sɛɹəmoʊni ðət tʃɹədɪʃən kleɪm deɪɾɪd tə ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz. ðə fɛstɪvəɾiz fəɹ ðə hʌntɝz hæd blɛndəɾ ɪndə ðə fist ə teɪvən, wɪð ɪts feɪm kɑntɛsts ən pɹaɪzəz fəɹ ɡlimən. ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst pɹaɪz ʌv ɔl, əz ɔlweɪz, wəd ɡoʊ fəɹ ðə bɛs tɛlɪŋ ə ðə ɡɹeɪt hʌn ə ðə hɔɹn.

The waxing moon lit the humid, night-dark streets of Illian, which still rang with celebration left over from daylight. In only a few more days, the Great Hunt of the Horn would be sent forth with pomp and ceremony that tradition claimed dated to the Age of Legends. The festivities for the Hunters had blended into the Feast of Teven, with its famed contests and prizes for gleemen. The greatest prize of all, as always, would go for the best telling of The Great Hunt of the Horn.

tənaɪt ðə ɡlimən ɛntɝteɪn ɪn ðə pæləsəz ən mæntʃənz ə ðə sɪɾi, wɛɹ ðə ɡɹeɪɾ ən maɪɾi dɪspɔɹɾɪd ðɛmsɛlvz, ən ðə hʌntɝz kʌm fɹəm ɛvɹi neɪʃən tə ɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ən faɪnd, ɪf nɑt ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ ɪtsɛlf, ət list ɪmɔɹtælɪɾi ɪn sɔŋ ən stɔɹi. ðeɪ wəɾ əv mjuzɪk ən dænsɪŋ, ən fænz ən aɪsəz tə dɪspɛl ðə jɪɹz fɝst ɹil hit, bʌt kɑɹnəvəl fɪl ðə stʃɹits, tu, ɪn ðə mun-bɹaɪt mʌɡi naɪt. ɛvɹi deɪ wɑz ə kɑɹnəvəl, əntɪl ðə hʌn dɪpɑɹɾəd, ən ɛvɹi naɪt.

Tonight the gleemen entertained in the palaces and mansions of the city, where the great and mighty disported themselves, and the Hunters come from every nation to ride out and find, if not the Horn of Valere itself, at least immortality in song and story. They would have music and dancing, and fans and ices to dispel the year's first real heat, but carnival filled the streets, too, in the moon-bright muggy night. Every day was a carnival, until the Hunt departed, and every night.

pipəl ɹæn pæs beɪl doʊmən ɪn mæsks ən kɑstumz bəzɑɹ ən fænsɪfəl, mɛni ʃoʊɪŋ tu mʌtʃ flɛʃ. ʃaʊɾɪŋ ən sɪŋɪŋ ðeɪ ɹæn, ə hæf dʌzən təɡɛðɝ, ðən skæɾɝd pɛɹz ɡɪɡəlɪŋ ən klʌtʃɪŋ itʃ ʌðɝ, ðən twɛnti ɪn ə ɹɔkəs nɑt. faɪɹwɝks kɹækəld ɪn ðə skaɪ, ɡoʊld ən sɪlvɝ bɝsts əɡɛns ðə blæk. ðəɹ wɝ ɔlmoʊst əz mɛni ɪluməneɪɾɝz ɪn ðə sɪɾi əz ðəɹ wɝ ɡlimən.

People ran past Bayle Domon in masks and costumes bizarre and fanciful, many showing too much flesh. Shouting and singing they ran, a half dozen together, then scattered pairs giggling and clutching each other, then twenty in a raucous knot. Fireworks crackled in the sky, gold and silver bursts against the black. There were almost as many Illuminators in the city as there were gleemen.

doʊmən spɛɹd lɪɾəl θɔt fəɹ faɪɹwɝks, əɹ fəɹ ðə hʌnt. hi wɑz ɑn ɪz weɪ tə mit mɛn i θɔt maɪt bi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kɪl hɪm.

Domon spared little thought for fireworks, or for the Hunt. He was on his way to meet men he thought might be trying to kill him.

hi kɹɔs ðə bɹɪdʒ ə flaʊɝz, oʊvɝ wʌn ə ðə sɪɾiz mɛni kənælz, ɪndə ðə pɝfjum kɔɹɾɝ, ðə pɔɹt dɪstʃɹɪkt ʌv ɪljən. ðə kənæl smɛld ə tu mɛni tʃeɪmbɝ pɑts, wɪð nɛvɝ ə saɪn ðət ðəɹ hæɾ ɛvɝ bɪn flaʊɝz nɪɹ ðə bɹɪdʒ. ðə kɔɹɾɝ smɛld ə hɛmp ən pɪtʃ fɹəm ðə ʃɪpjɑɹdz ən dɑks, ən saʊɝ hɑɹbɝ mʌd, ɔl ʌv ɪt meɪd fɪɹsɝ baɪ hiɾəd ɛɹ ðət sim nɪɹli dæmp ɪnʌf tə dʒɹɪŋk. doʊmən bɹið hɛvəli; ɛvɹi taɪm i ɹɪtɝn fɹəm ðə nɔɹθkaʊntʃɹi hi faʊn hɪmsɛlf sɝpɹaɪzd, fəɹ ɔl i hæd bɪn bɔɹn ðɛɹ, ət ði ɝli sʌmɝ hiɾ ɪn ɪljən.

He crossed the Bridge of Flowers, over one of the city's many canals, into the Perfumed Quarter, the port district of Illian. The canal smelled of too many chamber pots, with never a sign that there had ever been flowers near the bridge. The quarter smelled of hemp and pitch from the shipyards and docks, and sour harbor mud, all of it made fiercer by heated air that seemed nearly damp enough to drink. Domon breathed heavily; every time he returned from the northcountry he found himself surprised, for all he had been born there, at the early summer heat in Illian.

ɪn wʌn hæn i kæɹiɾ ə staʊt kʌdʒəl, ən ði ʌðɝ hæn ɹɛstəɾ ɑn ðə hɪlt ə ðə ʃɔɹt sɔɹɾ i hæɾ ɔfən juzd ɪn dɪfɛndɪŋ ðə dɛks ə hɪz ɹɪvɝ tʃɹeɪɾɝ fɹəm bɹɪɡænz. noʊ fju fʊtpædz stɔk ðiz naɪts ə ɹɛvəlɹi, wɛɹ ðə pɪkɪŋz wɝ ɹɪtʃ ən moʊst wɝ dip ɪn waɪn.

In one hand he carried a stout cudgel, and the other hand rested on the hilt of the short sword he had often used in defending the decks of his river trader from brigands. No few footpads stalked these nights of revelry, where the pickings were rich and most were deep in wine.

jɛɾ i wɑz ə bɹɔd, mʌskjəlɝ mæn, ən nʌn ə ðoʊz aʊt fəɹ ə kætʃ ʌv ɡoʊl θɔɾ ɪm ɹɪtʃ ɪnʌf, ɪn ɪz pleɪn-kʌt koʊt, tə ɹɪsk ɪz saɪz ən ɪz kʌdʒəl. ðə fju hu kɑɾ ə klɪɹ ɡlɪmps ə hɪm, wən i pæs θɹu laɪt spɪlɪŋ fɹəm ə wɪndoʊ, ɛdʒ bæk tɪl i wɑz wɛl pæst. dɑɹk hɛɹ ðət hʌŋ tə hɪz ʃoʊldɝz ən ə lɔŋ bɪɹd ðət lɛft ɪz ʌpɝ lɪp bɛɹ fɹeɪmd ə ɹaʊn feɪs, bʌt ðət feɪs hæd nɛvɝ bɪn sɑft, ən naʊ ɪt wɑz sɛɾ əz ɡɹɪmli əz ɪf i mɛn tə bæɾɝ ɪz weɪ θɹu ə wɔl. hi hæd mɛn tə mit, ən i wɑz nɑt hæpi əbaʊɾ ɪt.

Yet he was a broad, muscular man, and none of those out for a catch of gold thought him rich enough, in his plain-cut coat, to risk his size and his cudgel. The few who caught a clear glimpse of him, when he passed through light spilling from a window, edged back till he was well past. Dark hair that hung to his shoulders and a long beard that left his upper lip bare framed a round face, but that face had never been soft, and now it was set as grimly as if he meant to batter his way through a wall. He had men to meet, and he was not happy about it.

mɔɹ ɹɛvəlɝz ɹæn pæst sɪŋɪŋ ɔf-ki, waɪn mæŋɡəlɪŋ ðɛɹ wɝdz. "ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ," maɪ eɪdʒd ɡɹændmʌðɝ! doʊmən θɔt ɡlʌmli. ɪt bi maɪ ʃɪp aɪ də wɑnə hæŋ ɑn tə. ən maɪ laɪf, fɔɹtʃən pɹɪk mi.

More revelers ran past singing off-key, wine mangling their words. "The Horn of Valere," my aged grandmother! Domon thought glumly. It be my ship I do want to hang on to. And my life, Fortune prick me.

hi pʊʃt ɪndə ən ɪn, ʌndɝ ə saɪn ʌv ə bɪɡ, waɪt-stʃɹaɪp bædʒɝ dænsɪŋ ɑn ɪts haɪn lɛɡz wɪð ə mæn kæɹiɪŋ ə sɪlvɝ ʃʌvəl. izɪŋ ðə bædʒɝ, ɪt wɑz kɔld, ðoʊ nɑɾ ivən niɾə saɪdɔɹoʊ, ði ɪnkipɝ, nu wʌt ðə neɪm mɛnt; ðəɹ hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn ən ɪn ə ðə neɪm ɪn ɪljən.

He pushed into an inn, under a sign of a big, white-striped badger dancing on its hind legs with a man carrying a silver shovel. Easing the Badger, it was called, though not even Nieda Sidoro, the innkeeper, knew what the name meant; there had always been an inn of the name in Illian.

ðə kɑmən ɹum, wɪð sɔdʌst ɑn ðə flɔɹ ən ə mjuzɪʃən sɔfli stʃɹʌmɪŋ ə twɛlv-stʃɹɪŋ bɪɾɝn ɪn wʌn ə ðə si foʊks sæd sɔŋz, wɑz wɛl laɪɾəd ən kwaɪət. niɾə əlaʊd noʊ kəmoʊʃən ɪn əɹ pleɪs, ən əɹ nɛfju, bili, wɑz bɪɡ ɪnʌf tə kæɹi ə mæn aʊt wɪð iðɝ hænd. seɪlɝz, dɑkwɝkɝz, ən wɛɹhaʊsmən keɪm tə ðə bædʒɝ fəɹ ə dʒɹɪŋk ən meɪbi ə lɪɾəl tɔk, fəɹ ə ɡeɪm ə stoʊnz əɹ dɑɹts. ðə ɹum wɑz hæf fʊl naʊ; ivən mɛn u laɪkt kwaɪət hæd bɪn lʊɹɾ aʊt baɪ kɑɹnəvəl. ðə tɔk wɑz sɑft, bʌt doʊmən kɑt mɛnʃənz ə ðə hʌnt, ən ə ðə fɔls dʒɹæɡən ðə mʊɹændiənz hæd teɪkən, ən ə ðə wʌn ðə tɛɹənz wɝ tʃeɪsɪŋ θɹu hæɾən mɝk. ðəɹ sim tə bi səm kwɛstʃən wɛðɝ ɪt wəd bi pɹɛfɝəbəl tə si ðə fɔls dʒɹæɡən daɪ, əɹ ðə tɛɹənz.

The common room, with sawdust on the floor and a musician softly strumming a twelve-stringed bittern in one of the Sea Folk's sad songs, was well lighted and quiet. Nieda allowed no commotion in her place, and her nephew, Bili, was big enough to carry a man out with either hand. Sailors, dockworkers, and warehousemen came to the Badger for a drink and maybe a little talk, for a game of stones or darts. The room was half full now; even men who liked quiet had been lured out by carnival. The talk was soft, but Domon caught mentions of the Hunt, and of the false Dragon the Murandians had taken, and of the one the Tairens were chasing through Haddon Mirk. There seemed to be some question whether it would be preferable to see the false Dragon die, or the Tairens.

doʊmən ɡɹɪməst. fɔls dʒɹæɡənz! fɔɹtʃən pɹɪk mi, ðəɹ bi noʊ pleɪs seɪf ðiz deɪz. bʌɾ i hæd noʊ ɹil kɛɹ fəɹ fɔls dʒɹæɡənz, ɛni mɔɹ ðən fəɹ ðə hʌnt.

Domon grimaced. False Dragons! Fortune prick me, there be no place safe these days. But he had no real care for false Dragons, any more than for the Hunt.

ðə staʊt pɹəpɹaɪətʃɹəs, wɪð əɹ hɛɹ ɹoʊld ət ðə bæk ə hɝ hɛd, wɑz waɪpɪŋ ə mʌɡ, kipɪŋ ə ʃɑɹp aɪ ɑn əɹ ɪstæblɪʃmənt. ʃi dɪd nɑt stɑp wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ, əɹ ivən lʊk ət hɪm, ɹɪli, bʌɾ əɹ lɛft aɪləd dʒɹupt, ən əɹ aɪz slæntəd təwɔɹd θɹi mɛn əɾ ə teɪbəl ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ. ðeɪ wɝ kwaɪəɾ ivən fəɹ ðə bædʒɝ, ɔlmoʊst sɑmbɝ, ən ðɛɹ bɛl-ʃeɪp vɛlvət kæps ən dɑɹk koʊts, ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd əkɹɔs ðə tʃɛst ɪn bɑɹz ə sɪlvɝ ən skɑɹləɾ ən ɡoʊld, stʊɾ aʊɾ əmʌŋ ðə pleɪn dʒɹɛs ə ði ʌðɝ peɪtʃɹənz.

The stout proprietress, with her hair rolled at the back of her head, was wiping a mug, keeping a sharp eye on her establishment. She did not stop what she was doing, or even look at him, really, but her left eyelid drooped, and her eyes slanted toward three men at a table in the corner. They were quiet even for the Badger, almost somber, and their bell-shaped velvet caps and dark coats, embroidered across the chest in bars of silver and scarlet and gold, stood out among the plain dress of the other patrons.

doʊmən saɪɾ ən tʊk ə teɪbəl ɪn ə kɔɹnɝ baɪ hɪmsɛlf. kɛɹhinɪn, ðɪs taɪm. hi tʊk ə mʌɡ ʌv bɹaʊn eɪl fɹəm ə sɝvɪŋ ɡɝl ən dʒɹu ə lɔŋ swɑloʊ. wən i loʊɝd ðə mʌɡ, ðə θɹi mɛn ɪn stʃɹaɪp koʊts wɝ stændɪŋ bɪsaɪɾ ɪz teɪbəl. hi meɪɾ ən ʌnəbtʃɹusɪv dʒɛstʃɝ, tə lɛt niɾə noʊ ðəɾ i dɪd nɑt nid bili.

Domon sighed and took a table in a corner by himself. Cairhienin, this time. He took a mug of brown ale from a serving girl and drew a long swallow. When he lowered the mug, the three men in striped coats were standing beside his table. He made an unobtrusive gesture, to let Nieda know that he did not need Bili.

"kæptən doʊmən?" ðeɪ wɝ ɔl θɹi nɑndɪskɹɪpt, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ən ɛɹ əbaʊt ðə spikɝ ðət meɪd doʊmən teɪk ɪm fəɹ ðɛɹ liɾɝ. ðeɪ dɪd nɑɾ əpɪɹ tə bi ɑɹmd; dɪspaɪt ðɛɹ faɪn kloʊðz, ðeɪ lʊkt əz ɪf ðeɪ dɪd nɑt nid tə bi. ðəɹ wɝ hɑɹɾ aɪz ɪn ðoʊz soʊ vɛɹi ɔɹɾənɛɹi feɪsəz. "kæptən beɪl doʊmən, ʌv ðə spɹeɪ?"

"Captain Domon?" They were all three nondescript, but there was an air about the speaker that made Domon take him for their leader. They did not appear to be armed; despite their fine clothes, they looked as if they did not need to be. There were hard eyes in those so very ordinary faces. "Captain Bayle Domon, of the Spray?"

doʊmən ɡeɪv ə ʃɔɹt nɑd, ən ðə θɹi sæt daʊn wɪθaʊt weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ən ɪnvɪteɪʃən. ðə seɪm mæn dɪd ðə tɔkɪŋ; ði ʌðɝ tu dʒʌst wɑtʃt, hɑɹdli blɪŋkɪŋ. ɡɑɹdz, doʊmən θɔt, fəɹ ɔl ðɛɹ faɪn kloʊðz. hu də hi bi tə hæv ə pɛɹ ʌv ɡɑɹdz tə lʊk oʊvɝ hɪm?

Domon gave a short nod, and the three sat down without waiting for an invitation. The same man did the talking; the other two just watched, hardly blinking. Guards, Domon thought, for all their fine clothes. Who do he be to have a pair of guards to look over him?

"kæptən doʊmən, wɪv ə pɝsənɑdʒ u mʌs bi bɹɔt fɹəm min tə ɪljən."

"Captain Domon, we have a personage who must be brought from Mayene to Illian."

"spɹeɪ bi ə ɹɪvɝ kɹæft," doʊmən kʌɾ ɪm ɔf. "hɝ dʒɹæf bi ʃæloʊ, ən ʃiz noʊ ðə kil fəɹ dip wɔɾɝ." ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ɪɡzækli tʃɹu, bʌt kloʊs ɪnʌf fəɹ lænzmɪn. ət list ɪt bi ə tʃeɪnʒ fɹəm tɛɹ. ðeɪ bi ɡɛɾɪŋ smɑɹɾɝ.

"Spray be a river craft," Domon cut him off. "Her draft be shallow, and she has no the keel for deep water." It was not exactly true, but close enough for landsmen. At least it be a change from Tear. They be getting smarter.

ðə mæn simd ʌnpɝtɝbd ət ði ɪntɝʌpʃən. "wi hæd hɝd jə wɝ ɡɪvɪŋ ʌp ðə ɹɪvɝ tʃɹeɪd."

The man seemed unperturbed at the interruption. "We had heard you were giving up the river trade."

"meɪbi aɪ du, ən meɪbi noʊ. aɪ hæv noʊ dɪsaɪɾɪd." hi hæd, ðoʊ. hi wəd nɑt ɡoʊ bæk ʌpɹɪvɝ, bæk tə ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz, fəɹ ɔl ðə sɪlk ʃɪpt ɪn tɛɹən bɑɾəmz. sɑldəiən fɝz ən aɪs pɛpɝz wɝ nɑt wɝθ ɪt, ən ɪt hæd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðə fɔls dʒɹæɡən i hæd hɝɾ ə ðɛɹ. bʌɾ i wʌndɝɾ əɡɛn haʊ ɛniwʌn nu. hi hæd nɑt spoʊkən ʌv ɪt tə ɛniwʌn, jɛt ði ʌðɝz hæd noʊn, tu.

"Maybe I do, and maybe no. I have no decided." He had, though. He would not go back upriver, back to the Borderlands, for all the silk shipped in Tairen bottoms. Saldaean furs and ice peppers were not worth it, and it had nothing to do with the false Dragon he had heard of there. But he wondered again how anyone knew. He had not spoken of it to anyone, yet the others had known, too.

"ju kən koʊs tə min izəli ɪnʌf. ʃʊɹli, kæptən, jə wəd bi wɪlɪŋ tə seɪl əlɔŋ ðə ʃɔɹlaɪn fəɹ ə θaʊzənd ɡoʊl mɑɹks."

"You can coast to Mayene easily enough. Surely, Captain, you would be willing to sail along the shoreline for a thousand gold marks."

dɪspaɪt hɪmsɛlf, doʊmən ɡɑɡəld. ɪt wɑz fɔɹ taɪmz ðə læst ɔfɝ, ən ðət hæd bɪn ɪnʌf tə meɪk ə mænz dʒɔ dʒɹɑp. "hu dʒju wɑn mi tə fɛtʃ fəɹ ðæt? ðə fɝst ə min hɝsɛlf? hæz tɛɹ faɪnəli fɔɹst əɹ ɔl ðə weɪ aʊt, ðɛn?"

Despite himself, Domon goggled. It was four times the last offer, and that had been enough to make a man's jaw drop. "Who do you want me to fetch for that? The First of Mayene herself? Has Tear finally forced her all the way out, then?"

"ju nid noʊ neɪmz, kæptən." ðə mæn sɛɾ ə lɑɹdʒ lɛðɝ paʊtʃ ɑn ðə teɪbəl, ən ə sil pɑɹtʃmənt. ðə paʊtʃ klɪŋk hɛvəli əz i pʊʃt əm əkɹɔs ðə teɪbəl. ðə bɪɡ ɹɛd wæks sɝkəl hoʊldɪŋ ðə foʊldəd pɑɹtʃmənt ʃʌt bɔɹ ðə mɛni-ɹeɪd ɹaɪzɪŋ sʌn ə kɛɹhin. "tu hʌnʒɹəd ɑn əkaʊnt. fəɹ ə θaʊzən mɑɹks, aɪ θɪŋk jə nid noʊ neɪmz. ɡɪv ðæt, sil ənbɹoʊkən, tə ðə pɔɹt kæptən ə min, ən hɪl ɡɪv jə θɹi hʌnʒɹəd mɔɹ, ən jəɹ pæsənʒɝ. əl hæn oʊvɝ ðə ɹɪmeɪndɝ wən jəɹ pæsənʒɝ ɪz dɪlɪvɝd hɪɹ. soʊ lɔŋ əz juv meɪd noʊ ɛfɝt tə dɪskʌvɝ ðət pɝsənɑdʒəz aɪdɛntəɾi."

"You need no names, Captain." The man set a large leather pouch on the table, and a sealed parchment. The pouch clinked heavily as he pushed them across the table. The big red wax circle holding the folded parchment shut bore the many-rayed Rising Sun of Cairhien. "Two hundred on account. For a thousand marks, I think you need no names. Give that, seal unbroken, to the Port Captain of Mayene, and he will give you three hundred more, and your passenger. I will hand over the remainder when your passenger is delivered here. So long as you have made no effort to discover that personage's identity."

doʊmən dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ. fɔɹtʃən, ɪt bi wɝθ ðə vɔɪədʒ ɪf ðəɹ bi nɛvɝ ənʌðɝ pɛni bɪɑnd wʌt bi ɪn ðət sæk. ən ə θaʊzənd wɑz mɔɹ mʌni ðən i wəd klɪɹ ɪn θɹi jɪɹz. hi səspɛktəd ðəɾ ɪf i pɹoʊbd ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ, ðəɹ wəd bi ʌðɝ hɪns, dʒʌs hɪns, ðət ðə vɔɪədʒ ɪnvɑlv hɪɾən dilɪŋz bɪtwin ɪljənz kaʊnsəl ə naɪn ən ðə fɝst ə min. ðə fɝsts sɪɾi-steɪt wɑz ə pɹɑvəns ə tiɹ ɪn ɔl bʌt neɪm, ən ʃi wəd noʊ daʊt laɪk ɪljənz eɪd. ən ðəɹ wɝ mɛni ɪn ɪljən u sɛɾ ɪt wɑz taɪm fəɹ ənʌðɝ wɔɹ, ðət tiɹ wɑz teɪkɪŋ mɔɹ ðən ə fɛɹ ʃɛɹ ə ðə tʃɹeɪɾ ɑn ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz. ə laɪkli nɛt tə snɛɹ hɪm, ɪf i hæd nɑt sin θɹi laɪk ɪɾ ɪn ðə pæs mʌnθ.

Domon drew a deep breath. Fortune, it be worth the voyage if there be never another penny beyond what be in that sack. And a thousand was more money than he would clear in three years. He suspected that if he probed a little more, there would be other hints, just hints, that the voyage involved hidden dealings between Illian's Council of Nine and the First of Mayene. The First's city-state was a province of Tear in all but name, and she would no doubt like Illian's aid. And there were many in Illian who said it was time for another war, that Tear was taking more than a fair share of the trade on the Sea of Storms. A likely net to snare him, if he had not seen three like it in the past month.

hi ɹitʃt tə teɪk ðə paʊtʃ, ən ðə mæn u hæd dʌn ɔl ðə tɔkɪŋ kɑɾ ɪz ɹɪst. doʊmən ɡlɛɹɾ ət hɪm, bʌɾ i lʊk bæk ʌndɪstɝbd.

He reached to take the pouch, and the man who had done all the talking caught his wrist. Domon glared at him, but he looked back undisturbed.

"ju mʌst seɪl əz sun əz pɑsəbəl, kæptən."

"You must sail as soon as possible, Captain."

"æt fɝs laɪt," doʊmən ɡɹaʊld, ən ðə mæn nɑɾəd ən ɹilist ɪz hoʊld.

"At first light," Domon growled, and the man nodded and released his hold.

"æt fɝs laɪt, ðɛn, kæptən doʊmən. ɹɪmɛmbɝ, dɪskɹɛʃən kips ə mæn əlaɪv tə spɛn ɪz mʌni."

"At first light, then, Captain Domon. Remember, discretion keeps a man alive to spend his money."

doʊmən wɑtʃt ðə θɹi ʌv əm liv, ðən stɛɹd saʊɝli ət ðə paʊtʃ ən ðə pɑɹtʃmən ɑn ðə teɪbəl ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm. sʌmwʌn wɑntəɾ ɪm tə ɡoʊ ist. tiɹ əɹ min, ɪt dɪd nɑt mæɾɝ soʊ lɔŋ əz i wɛn ist. hi θɔɾ i nu hu wɑntəɾ ɪt. ən ðən əɡɛn, aɪ hæv noʊ ə klu tə ðɛm. hu kəd noʊ hu wɑz ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd? bʌɾ i nu ðət dɑɹkfɹɛnz hæd bɪn æftɝ ɪm sɪns bɪfɔɹ i lɛf mɛɹəbən tə kʌm bæk daʊnɹɪvɝ. dɑɹkfɹɛnz ən tʃɹɑləks. ʌv ðæt, hi wɑz ʃʊɹ. ðə ɹil kwɛstʃən, ðə wʌn i hæd nɑɾ ivən ə ɡlɪmɝ ʌv ən ænsɝ fɔɹ, wɑz waɪ?

Domon watched the three of them leave, then stared sourly at the pouch and the parchment on the table in front of him. Someone wanted him to go east. Tear or Mayene, it did not matter so long as he went east. He thought he knew who wanted it. And then again, I have no a clue to them. Who could know who was a Darkfriend? But he knew that Darkfriends had been after him since before he left Marabon to come back downriver. Darkfriends and Trollocs. Of that, he was sure. The real question, the one he had not even a glimmer of an answer for, was why?

"tʃɹʌbəl, beɪl?" niɾə æskt. "ju də lʊk əz ɪf jə hæd sin ə tʃɹɑlɑk." ʃi ɡɪɡəld, ən ɪmpɹɑbəbəl saʊn fɹəm ə wʊmən əɹ saɪz. laɪk moʊs pipəl u hæd nɛvɝ bɪn tə ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz, niɾə dɪd nɑt bɪliv ɪn tʃɹɑləks. hi hæd tʃɹaɪd tɛlɪŋ əɹ ðə tʃɹuθ ʌv ɪt; ʃi ɛndʒɔɪɾ ɪz stɔɹiz, ən θɔt ðeɪ wɝ ɔl laɪz. ʃi dɪd nɑt bɪliv ɪn snoʊ, iðɝ.

"Trouble, Bayle?" Nieda asked. "You do look as if you had seen a Trolloc." She giggled, an improbable sound from a woman her size. Like most people who had never been to the Borderlands, Nieda did not believe in Trollocs. He had tried telling her the truth of it; she enjoyed his stories, and thought they were all lies. She did not believe in snow, either.

"noʊ tʃɹʌbəl, niɾə." hi əntaɪd ðə paʊtʃ, dʌɡ ə kɔɪn aʊt wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ, ən tɔst ɪt tə hɝ. "dʒɹɪŋks fəɹ ɛvɹiwʌn tɪl ðət də ɹʌn aʊt, ðən əl ɡɪv jə ənʌðɝ."

"No trouble, Nieda." He untied the pouch, dug a coin out without looking, and tossed it to her. "Drinks for everyone till that do run out, then I'll give you another."

niɾə lʊkt ət ðə kɔɪn ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. "eɪ tɑɹ vəlɑn mɑɹk! dʒju bi tʃɹeɪɾɪŋ wɪð ðə wɪtʃəz naʊ, beɪl?"

Nieda looked at the coin in surprise. "A Tar Valon mark! Do you be trading with the witches now, Bayle?"

"noʊ," hi sɛd hɔɹsli. "ðæɾ aɪ də nɑt!"

"No," he said hoarsely. "That I do not!"

ʃi bɪt ðə kɔɪn, ðən kwɪkli snʌɡd ɪɾ əweɪ bɪhaɪn əɹ bɹɔd bɛlt. "wɛl, ɪt bi ɡoʊl fəɹ ðæt. ən aɪ səspɛk ðə wɪtʃəz bi noʊ soʊ bæɾ əz səm meɪk əm aʊt, ɛniweɪ. aɪd noʊ seɪ soʊ mʌtʃ tə mɛni mɛn. aɪ noʊ ə mʌni tʃeɪnɝ u də hændəl sʌtʃ. jəl noʊ hæv tə ɡɪmi ənʌðɝ, wɪð əz fju əz bi hɪɹ tənaɪt. mɔɹ eɪl fəɹ ju, beɪl?"

She bit the coin, then quickly snugged it away behind her broad belt. "Well, it be gold for that. And I suspect the witches be no so bad as some make them out, anyway. I'd no say so much to many men. I know a money changer who do handle such. You'll no have to give me another, with as few as be here tonight. More ale for you, Bayle?"

hi nɑɾəd nʌmbli, ðoʊ hɪz mʌɡ wɑz stɪl ɔlmoʊs fʊl, ən ʃi tʃɹʌndəld ɔf. ʃi wɑz ə fɹɛnd, ən wəd nɑt spik ʌv wʌt ʃi hæd sin. hi sæt stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə lɛðɝ paʊtʃ. ənʌðɝ mʌɡ wɑz bɹɔt bɪfɔɹ i kəd meɪk hɪmsɛlf oʊpən ɪɾ ɪnʌf tə lʊk ət ðə kɔɪnz ɪnsaɪd. hi stɝɾ əm wɪð ə kælʌz fɪŋɡɝ. ɡoʊl mɑɹks ɡlɪɾɝd ʌp əɾ ɪm ɪn ðə læmplaɪt, ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðɛm bɛɹɪŋ ðə dæmɪŋ fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn. hɝidli hi taɪd ðə bæɡ. deɪnʒɝəs kɔɪnz. wʌn əɹ tu maɪt pæs, bʌt soʊ mɛni wəd seɪ tə moʊs pipəl ɪɡzækli wʌt niɾə θɔt. ðəɹ wɝ tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪɾ ɪn ðə sɪɾi, ən ɔlðoʊ ðəɹ wɑz noʊ lɔ ɪn ɪljən əɡɛns dilɪŋ wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ, hi wəd nɛvɝ meɪk ɪt tə ə mædʒəstʃɹeɪɾ ɪf ðə waɪtkloʊks hɝɾ ə ðɪs. ðiz mɛn hæd meɪd ʃʊɹ i wəd nɑt sɪmpli teɪk ðə ɡoʊld ən steɪ ɪn ɪljən.

He nodded numbly, though his mug was still almost full, and she trundled off. She was a friend, and would not speak of what she had seen. He sat staring at the leather pouch. Another mug was brought before he could make himself open it enough to look at the coins inside. He stirred them with a callused finger. Gold marks glittered up at him in the lamplight, every one of them bearing the damning Flame of Tar Valon. Hurriedly he tied the bag. Dangerous coins. One or two might pass, but so many would say to most people exactly what Nieda thought. There were Children of the Light in the city, and although there was no law in Illian against dealing with Aes Sedai, he would never make it to a magistrate if the Whitecloaks heard of this. These men had made sure he would not simply take the gold and stay in Illian.

waɪl i wɑz sɪɾɪŋ ðəɹ wɝiɪŋ, jɑɹən mldæn, hɪz bɹuɾɪŋ, stɔɹk-laɪk sɛkən ɑn spɹeɪ, keɪm ɪndə ðə bædʒɝ wɪð ɪz bɹaʊz pʊl daʊn tə hɪz lɔŋ noʊz ən stʊɾ oʊvɝ ðə kæptənz teɪbəl. "kɑɹnz dɛd, kæptən."

While he was sitting there worrying, Yarin Maeldan, his brooding, stork-like second on Spray, came into the Badger with his brows pulled down to his long nose and stood over the captain's table. "Carn's dead, Captain."

doʊmən stɛɹɾ ət hɪm, fɹaʊnɪŋ. θɹi ʌðɝz ə hɪz mɛn hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bɪn kɪld, wʌn itʃ taɪm i ɹəfjuzd ə kəmɪʃən ðət wəd teɪk ɪm ist. ðə mædʒɪstʃɹeɪts hæd dʌn nʌθɪŋ; ðə stʃɹits wɝ deɪnʒɝəs ət naɪt, ðeɪ sɛd, ən seɪlɝz ə ɹʌf ən kwɔɹəlsəm lɑt. mædʒɪstʃɹeɪts sɛldəm tʃɹʌbəl ðɛmsɛlvz wɪð wʌt hæpən ɪn ðə pɝfjum kɔɹɾɝ, əz lɔŋ əz noʊ ɹɪspɛktəbəl sɪɾəzənz wɝ ɪnʒɝd.

Domon stared at him, frowning. Three others of his men had already been killed, one each time he refused a commission that would take him east. The magistrates had done nothing; the streets were dangerous at night, they said, and sailors a rough and quarrelsome lot. Magistrates seldom troubled themselves with what happened in the Perfumed Quarter, as long as no respectable citizens were injured.

"bʌt ðɪs taɪm aɪ dɪɾ æksɛp ðɛm," hi mʌɾɝd.

"But this time I did accept them," he muttered.

" 'tɪsn ɔl, kæptən," jɑɹən sɛd. "ðeɪ wɝkt kɑɹn wɪð naɪvz, laɪk ðeɪ wɑntəɾ ɪm tə tɛl əm sʌmθɪŋ. ən səm mɔɹ mɛn tʃɹaɪd tə snik əbɔɹd spɹeɪ nɑɾ ən aʊɝ ɡɔn. ðə dɑk wɑtʃ ɹæn əm ɔf. θɝd taɪm ɪn tɛn deɪz, ən aɪ nɛvɝ nu wɔɹf ɹæts tə bi soʊ pɝsɪstənt. ðeɪ laɪk tə lɛɾ ən əlɑɹm daɪ daʊn bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ tʃɹaɪ əɡɛn. ən sʌmbɑɾi tɔs maɪ ɹum ət ðə sɪlvɝ dɑlfən læs naɪt. tʊk səm sɪlvɝ, soʊ aɪd θɪŋk ɪt wɑz θivz, bʌt ðeɪ lɛf ðət bɛl bʌkəl ə maɪn, ðə wʌn sɛt wɪð ɡɑɹnəts ən munstoʊnz, laɪɪŋ ɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ɪn pleɪn saɪt. wʌts ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn, kæptən? ðə mɛn ɑɹ əfɹeɪd, ən ɪm ə lɪɾəl nɝvəs maɪsɛlf."

" 'Tisn't all, Captain," Yarin said. "They worked Carn with knives, like they wanted him to tell them something. And some more men tried to sneak aboard Spray not an hour gone. The dock watch ran them off. Third time in ten days, and I never knew wharf rats to be so persistent. They like to let an alarm die down before they try again. And somebody tossed my room at the Silver Dolphin last night. Took some silver, so I'd think it was thieves, but they left that belt buckle of mine, the one set with garnets and moonstones, lying right out in plain sight. What's going on, Captain? The men are afraid, and I'm a little nervous myself."

doʊmən ɹɪɹd tə hɪz fit. "ɹs ðə kɹu, jɑɹən. faɪn əm ən tɛl əm spɹeɪ seɪlz əz sun əz ðəɹ də bi mɛn ɪnʌf əbɔɹd tə hændəl hɝ." stʌfɪŋ ðə pɑɹtʃmən ɪndə hɪz koʊt pɑkət, hi snætʃt ʌp ðə bæɡ ʌv ɡoʊld ən pʊʃt ɪz sɛkən aʊt ðə dɔɹ əhɛɾ ə hɪm. "ɹs ðɛm, jɑɹən, fəɹ əl liv ɛni mæn u noʊ meɪks ɪt, stændɪŋ ɑn ðə ki əz i ɪz."

Domon reared to his feet. "Roust the crew, Yarin. Find them and tell them Spray sails as soon as there do be men enough aboard to handle her." Stuffing the parchment into his coat pocket, he snatched up the bag of gold and pushed his second out the door ahead of him. "Roust them, Yarin, for I'll leave any man who no makes it, standing on the quay as he is."

doʊmən ɡeɪv jɑɹən ə ʃʌv tə stɑɹɾ ɪm ɹʌnɪŋ, ðən stɔkt ɔf təwɔɹd ðə dɑks. ivən fʊtpædz u hɝd ðə klɪŋkɪŋ ə ðə paʊtʃ i kæɹid stɪɹd klɪɹ ə hɪm, fəɹ i wɔk naʊ laɪk ə mæn gɑnə də mɝɾɝ.

Domon gave Yarin a shove to start him running, then stalked off toward the docks. Even footpads who heard the clinking of the pouch he carried steered clear of him, for he walked now like a man going to do murder.

ðəɹ wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi kɹumɪn skɹæmbəlɪŋ əbɔɹd spɹeɪ wən i ɝaɪvd, ən mɔɹ ɹʌnɪŋ bɛɹfʊt daʊn ðə stoʊn ki. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌɾ i fɪɹd wɑz pɝsuɪŋ hɪm, əɹ ivən ðəɾ ɛniθɪŋ dɪd pɝsu hɪm, bʌt ðeɪ nu hi meɪd ɡʊd pɹɑfəts, ən æftɝ ði ɪliɑnɝ weɪ, hi ɡeɪv ʃɛɹz tə ðə kɹu.

There were already crewmen scrambling aboard Spray when he arrived, and more running barefoot down the stone quay. They did not know what he feared was pursuing him, or even that anything did pursue him, but they knew he made good profits, and after the Illianer way, he gave shares to the crew.

spɹeɪ wɑz eɪɾi fit lɔŋ, wɪð tu mæsts, ən bɹɔɾ ɪn ðə bim, wɪð ɹum fəɹ dɛk kɑɹɡoʊ əz wɛl əz ɪn ðə hoʊlz. dɪspaɪt wʌt doʊmən hæd toʊl ðə kɛɹhinɪn - ɪf ðeɪ hæd bɪn kɛɹhinɪn - hi θɔt ʃi kəd stæn ði oʊpən wɔɾɝ. ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz wɑz kwaɪəɾɝ ɪn ðə sʌmɝ.

Spray was eighty feet long, with two masts, and broad in the beam, with room for deck cargo as well as in the holds. Despite what Domon had told the Cairhienin - if they had been Cairhienin - he thought she could stand the open water. The Sea of Storms was quieter in the summer.

"ʃil əv tə," hi mʌɾɝd, ən stʃɹoʊd bɪloʊ tə hɪz kæbən.

"She'll have to," he muttered, and strode below to his cabin.

hi tɔs ðə sæk ʌv ɡoʊld ɑn ɪz bɛd, bɪl nitli əɡɛns ðə hʌl laɪk ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls ɪn ðə stɝn kæbən, ən dʌɡ aʊt ðə pɑɹtʃmənt. laɪɾɪŋ ə læntɝn, hæŋɪŋ ɪn ɪts swɪvəl fɹəm ði oʊvɝhɛd, hi stʌɾid ðə sil dɑkjəmɛnt, tɝnɪŋ ɪɾ əz ɪf i kəd ɹid wʌt wɑz ɪnsaɪd wɪθaʊɾ oʊpənɪŋ ɪt. ə ɹæp ɑn ðə dɔɹ meɪɾ ɪm fɹaʊn.

He tossed the sack of gold on his bed, built neatly against the hull like everything else in the stern cabin, and dug out the parchment. Lighting a lantern, hanging in its swivel from the overhead, he studied the sealed document, turning it as if he could read what was inside without opening it. A rap on the door made him frown.

"kʌm."

"Come."

jɑɹən stʌk ɪz hɛɾ ɪn. "ðeɪɹ ɔl əbɔɹd bʌt θɹi aɪ kʊdn faɪnd, kæptən. bʌɾ aɪv spɹɛd ðə wɝd θɹu ɛvɹi tævɝn, hɛl, ən kɹɪb ɪn ðə kɔɹɾɝ. ðəl bi əbɔɹd bɪfɔɹ ɪts laɪɾ ɪnʌf tə stɑɹɾ ʌpɹɪvɝ."

Yarin stuck his head in. "They're all aboard but three I couldn't find, Captain. But I've spread the word through every tavern, hell, and crib in the quarter. They'll be aboard before it's light enough to start upriver."

"spɹeɪ də seɪl naʊ. tə si." doʊmən kʌɾ ɔf jɑɹənz pɹoʊɾɛsts əbaʊt laɪɾ ən taɪdz, ən spɹeɪ nɑt biɪŋ bɪl fəɹ ði oʊpən si. "naʊ! spɹeɪ kən klɪɹ ðə bɑɹz ət dɛd loʊ taɪd. juv noʊ fɝɡɑɾən haʊ tə seɪl baɪ ðə stɑɹz, hæv ju? teɪk əɹ aʊt, jɑɹən. teɪk əɹ aʊt naʊ, ən kʌm bæk tə mi wən wi bi bɪɑn ðə bɹeɪkwɔɾɝ."

"Spray do sail now. To sea." Domon cut off Yarin's protests about light and tides, and Spray not being built for the open sea. "Now! Spray can clear the bars at dead low tide. You've no forgotten how to sail by the stars, have you? Take her out, Yarin. Take her out now, and come back to me when we be beyond the breakwater."

hɪz sɛkən hɛzɪteɪɾɪd - doʊmən nɛvɝ lɛɾ ə tʃɹɪki bɪɾ ə seɪlɪŋ pæs wɪθaʊɾ ɪm ɑn dɛk ɡɪvɪŋ ɔɹɾɝz, ən teɪkɪŋ spɹeɪ aʊɾ ɪn ðə naɪt wəd bi ɔl ə ðæt, ʃæloʊ dʒɹæft əɹ noʊ - ðən nɑɾəd ən vænɪʃt. ɪn moʊməns ðə saʊnz ə jɑɹən ʃaʊɾɪŋ ɔɹɾɝz ən bɛɹ fit θʌmpɪŋ ɑn ðə dɛks oʊvɝhɛd pɛnətʃɹeɪɾəd doʊmənz kæbən. hi ɪɡnɔɹd ðɛm, ivən wən ðə ʃɪp lɝtʃt, kætʃɪŋ ðə taɪd.

His second hesitated - Domon never let a tricky bit of sailing pass without him on deck giving orders, and taking Spray out in the night would be all of that, shallow draft or no - then nodded and vanished. In moments the sounds of Yarin shouting orders and bare feet thumping on the decks overhead penetrated Domon's cabin. He ignored them, even when the ship lurched, catching the tide.

faɪnəli hi lɪftəd ðə mæntəl ə ðə læntɝn ən stʌk ə naɪf ɪndə ðə fleɪm. smoʊk kɝld ʌp əz ɔɪl bɝn ɔf ðə bleɪd, bʌt bɪfɔɹ ðə mɛɾəl kəd tɝn ɹɛd, hi pʊʃt tʃɑɹts aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ ən pɹɛs ðə pɑɹtʃmən flæɾ ɑn ɪz dɛsk, wɝkɪŋ ðə hɑt stil sloʊli ʌndɝ ðə silɪŋ wæks. ðə tɑp foʊld lɪftəd.

Finally he lifted the mantle of the lantern and stuck a knife into the flame. Smoke curled up as oil burned off the blade, but before the metal could turn red, he pushed charts out of the way and pressed the parchment flat on his desk, working the hot steel slowly under the sealing wax. The top fold lifted.

ɪt wɑz ə sɪmpəl dɑkjəmɛnt, wɪθaʊt pɹiæmbəl əɹ səluteɪʃən, ən ɪt meɪd swɛt bɹeɪk aʊɾ ɑn ɪz fɔɹhɛd.

It was a simple document, without preamble or salutation, and it made sweat break out on his forehead.

ðə bɛɹɝ ə ðɪs ɪz ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd wɑntəɾ ɪn kɛɹhin fəɹ mɝɾɝz ən ʌðɝ faʊl kɹaɪmz, list əmʌŋ ðɛm, θɛft fɹəm əɹ pɝsən. wi kɔl əpɑn jə tə siz ðɪs mæn ən ɔl θɪŋz faʊn ɪn ɪz kipɪŋ, tə ðə smɔləst. əɹ ɹɛpɹəzɛntəɾɪv wɪl kʌm tə kæɹi əweɪ wʌt hiz stoʊlən fɹəm ʌs. lɛɾ ɔl i pəzɛsəz, seɪv wʌt wi kleɪm, ɡoʊ tə jə əz ɹɪwɔɹd fəɹ teɪkɪŋ hɪm. lɛt ðə vaɪl mɪskɹiən hɪmsɛlf bi hæŋd ɪmiɾiətli, ðəɾ ɪz ʃædoʊ-spɔn vɪləni noʊ lɔŋɡɝ teɪn ðə laɪt.

The bearer of this is a Darkfriend wanted in Cairhien for murders and other foul crimes, least among them, theft from Our Person. We call upon you to seize this man and all things found in his keeping, to the smallest. Our representative will come to carry away what he has stolen from Us. Let all he possesses, save what We claim, go to you as reward for taking him. Let the vile miscreant himself be hanged immediately, that his Shadow-spawned villainy no longer taint the Light.

sil baɪ əɹ hænd ɡɔlʒɹiən su ɹieɪɾən ɹi kɪŋ ə kɛɹhin dɪfɛndɝ ə ðə dʒɹæɡoʊnwɔl ɪn θɪn ɹɛd wæks bɪloʊ ðə sɪɡnətʃɝ wɝ ɪmpɹɛs ðə ɹaɪzɪŋ sʌn sil ə kɛɹhin ən ðə faɪv stɑɹz ə haʊs ɹieɪɾən.

Sealed by Our Hand Galldrian su Riatin Rie King of Cairhien Defender of the Dragonwall In thin red wax below the signature were impressed the Rising Sun seal of Cairhien and the Five Stars of House Riatin.

"dɪfɛndɝ ə ðə dʒɹæɡoʊnwɔl, maɪ eɪdʒd ɡɹændmʌðɝ," doʊmən kɹoʊkt. "faɪn ɹaɪt ðə mæn də hæv tə kɔl hɪmsɛlf ðəɾ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ."

"Defender of the Dragonwall, my aged grandmother," Domon croaked. "Fine right the man do have to call himself that any longer."

hi ɪɡzæmən ðə silz ən sɪɡnətʃɝ mɪnətli, hoʊldɪŋ ðə dɑkjəmɛn kloʊs tə ðə læmp, wɪð ɪz noʊz ɔl bʌt bɹʌʃɪŋ ðə pɑɹtʃmənt, bʌɾ i kəd faɪnd noʊ flɔ ɪn ðə wʌn, ən fəɹ ði ʌðɝ, hi hæd noʊ aɪdiə wʌt ɡɔlʒɹiənz hæn lʊk laɪk. ɪf ɪt wɑz nɑt ðə kɪŋ hɪmsɛlf u hæd saɪn ɪt, hi səspɛktəd ðət huɛvɝ hæd hæd meɪɾ ə ɡʊɾ ɪməteɪʃən ʌv ɡɔlʒɹiənz skɹɔl. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ɪt meɪd noʊ ɹil dɪfɝəns. ɪn tɛɹ, ðə lɛɾɝ wəd bi ɪnstənli dæmɪŋ ɪn ðə hænz ʌv ən ɪliɑnɝ. əɹ ɪn min, wɪð tɛɹən ɪnfluəns soʊ stʃɹɔŋ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ wɔɹ naʊ, ən mɛn fɹəm iðɝ pɔɹt keɪm ən wɛn fɹili, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz əz lɪɾəl lʌv fəɹ ɪliɑnɝz ɪn tiɹ əz ði ʌðɝ weɪ ɹaʊnd. ɪspɛʃli wɪð ən ɪkskjus laɪk ðɪs.

He examined the seals and signature minutely, holding the document close to the lamp, with his nose all but brushing the parchment, but he could find no flaw in the one, and for the other, he had no idea what Galldrian's hand looked like. If it was not the King himself who had signed it, he suspected that whoever had had made a good imitation of Galldrian's scrawl. In any case, it made no real difference. In Tear, the letter would be instantly damning in the hands of an Illianer. Or in Mayene, with Tairen influence so strong. There was no war now, and men from either port came and went freely, but there was as little love for Illianers in Tear as the other way round. Especially with an excuse like this.

fəɹ ə moʊmən i θɔɾ ə pʊɾɪŋ ðə pɑɹtʃmən ɪndə ðə læntɝnz fleɪm - ɪt wɑz ə deɪnʒɝəs θɪŋ tə hæv, ɪn tiɹ əɹ ɪljən əɹ ɛniwɛɹ i kəɾ ɪmædʒən - bʌt faɪnəli hi tʌkt ɪt kɛɹfəli ɪndə ə sikɹət kʌbihoʊl bɪhaɪn ɪz dɛsk, kənsil baɪ ə pænəl oʊnli hi nu haʊ tə oʊpən.

For a moment he thought of putting the parchment into the lantern's flame - it was a dangerous thing to have, in Tear or Illian or anywhere he could imagine - but finally he tucked it carefully into a secret cubbyhole behind his desk, concealed by a panel only he knew how to open.

"maɪ pəzɛʃənz, ɛ?"

"My possessions, eh?"

hi kəlɛktəɾ oʊl θɪŋz, əz mʌtʃ əz i kəd lɪvɪŋ ɑn ʃɪpbɔɹd. wʌɾ i kəd nɑt baɪ, kəz ɪt wɑz tu ɪkspɛnsɪv əɹ tu lɑɹdʒ, hi kəlɛktəd baɪ siɪŋ ən ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ. ɔl ðoʊz ɹɛmnəns ə taɪmz ɡɔn, ðoʊz wʌndɝz skæɾɝd ɝaʊn ðə wɝl ðət hæd fɝs pʊld ɪm əbɔɹɾ ə ʃɪp əz bɔɪ. hi hæɾ æɾəd fɔɹ tə hɪz kəlɛkʃən ɪn mɛɹədɑn ðɪs læs tʃɹɪp, ən ɪt hæd bɪn ðən ðət ðə dɑɹkfɹɛn pɝsut bɪɡæn. ən tʃɹɑləks, tu, fəɹ ə taɪm. hi hæd hɝd ðət waɪtbɹɪdʒ hæd bɪn bɝn tə ðə ɡɹaʊn ɹaɪɾ æftɝ i seɪl fɹəm ðɛɹ, ən ðəɹ hæd bɪn ɹumɝz ə mɹdʒɹɑl əz wɛl əz tʃɹɑləks. ɪt wɑz ðæt, ɔl ʌv ɪt təɡɛðɝ, ðət hæd fɝs kənvɪnst ɪm i wɑz nɑɾ ɪmædʒənɪŋ θɪŋz, ðət hæd hæɾ ɪm ɑn ɡɑɹd wən ðət fɝst ɑd kəmɪʃən wɑz ɔfɝd, tu mʌtʃ mʌni fəɹ ə sɪmpəl vɔɪədʒ tə tɛɹ, ən ə θɪn teɪl fəɹ ə ɹizən.

He collected old things, as much as he could living on shipboard. What he could not buy, because it was too expensive or too large, he collected by seeing and remembering. All those remnants of times gone, those wonders scattered around the world that had first pulled him aboard a ship as boy. He had added four to his collection in Maradon this last trip, and it had been then that the Darkfriend pursuit began. And Trollocs, too, for a time. He had heard that Whitebridge had been burned to the ground right after he sailed from there, and there had been rumors of Myrddraal as well as Trollocs. It was that, all of it together, that had first convinced him he was not imagining things, that had had him on guard when that first odd commission was offered, too much money for a simple voyage to Tear, and a thin tale for a reason.

dɪɡɪŋ ɪndə hɪz tʃɛst, hi sɛɾ aʊɾ ɑn ðə dɛsk wʌɾ i hæd bɑɾ ɪn mɛɹədɑn. ə laɪtstɪk, lɛft fɹəm ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz, əɹ soʊ ɪt wɑz sɛd. sɝɾənli noʊ wʌn nu ðə meɪkɪŋ ə ðɛm ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. ɪkspɛnsɪv, ðæt, ən ɹɛɹɝ ðən ən ɑnəs mædʒəstʃɹeɪt. ɪt lʊk laɪk ə pleɪn ɡlæs ɹɑd, θɪkɝ ðən ɪz θʌm ən nɑt kwaɪɾ əz lɔŋ əz ɪz fɔɹɑɹm, bʌt wən hɛld ɪn ðə hæn ɪt ɡloʊɾ əz bɹaɪtli əz ə læntɝn. laɪtstɪks ʃæɾɝd laɪk ɡlæs, tu; hi hæd nɪɹli lɔst spɹeɪ ɪn ðə faɪɝ kɑz baɪ ðə fɝst i hæɾ oʊnd. ə smɔl, eɪdʒ-dɑɹk aɪvɝi kɑɹvɪŋ ʌv ə mæn hoʊldɪŋ ə sɔɹd. ðə fɛloʊ hu soʊld ɪt kleɪmd ɪf jə hɛld ɪt lɔŋ ɪnʌf jə stɑɹɾəd tə fil wɔɹm. doʊmən nɛvɝ hæd, ən niðɝ hæɾ ɛni ʌv ðə kɹu hi lɛt hoʊld ɪt, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz oʊld, ən ðət wɑz ɪnʌf fəɹ doʊmən. ðə skʌl ʌv ə kæɾ əz bɪɡ əz ə laɪən, ən soʊ oʊld ɪt wɑz tɝn tə stoʊn. bʌt noʊ laɪən hæɾ ɛvɝ hæd fæŋz, ɔlmoʊs tʌsks, ə fʊt lɔŋ. ən ə θɪk dɪsk ðə saɪz ʌv ə mænz hænd, hæf waɪɾ ən hæf blæk, ə sɪnwəs laɪn sɛpɝeɪɾɪŋ ðə kʌlɝz. ðə ʃɑpkipɝ ɪn mɛɹədɑn hæd sɛɾ ɪt wɑz fɹəm ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz, θɪŋkɪŋ i laɪd, bʌt doʊmən hæd hæɡəld oʊnli ə lɪɾəl bɪfɔɹ peɪɪŋ, kəz i ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd wʌt ðə ʃɑpkipɝ dɪd nɑt: ði eɪntʃən sɪmbəl ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ fɹəm bɪfɔɹ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld. nɑɾ ə seɪf θɪŋ tə hæv, pɹɪsaɪsli, bʌt niðɝ ə θɪŋ tə bi pæst ʌp baɪ ə mæn wɪð ə fæsəneɪʃən fəɹ ði oʊld.

Digging into his chest, he set out on the desk what he had bought in Maradon. A lightstick, left from the Age of Legends, or so it was said. Certainly no one knew the making of them any longer. Expensive, that, and rarer than an honest magistrate. It looked like a plain glass rod, thicker than his thumb and not quite as long as his forearm, but when held in the hand it glowed as brightly as a lantern. Lightsticks shattered like glass, too; he had nearly lost Spray in the fire caused by the first he had owned. A small, age-dark ivory carving of a man holding a sword. The fellow who sold it claimed if you held it long enough you started to feel warm. Domon never had, and neither had any of the crew he let hold it, but it was old, and that was enough for Domon. The skull of a cat as big as a lion, and so old it was turned to stone. But no lion had ever had fangs, almost tusks, a foot long. And a thick disk the size of a man's hand, half white and half black, a sinuous line separating the colors. The shopkeeper in Maradon had said it was from the Age of Legends, thinking he lied, but Domon had haggled only a little before paying, because he recognized what the shopkeeper did not: the ancient symbol of Aes Sedai from before the Breaking of the World. Not a safe thing to have, precisely, but neither a thing to be passed up by a man with a fascination for the old.

ən ɪt wɑz hɑɹtstoʊn. ðə ʃɑpkipɝ hæd nɛvɝ dɛɹɾ æd ðət tə wʌɾ i θɔt wɝ laɪz. noʊ ɹɪvɝfɹʌnt ʃɑpkipɝ ɪn mɛɹədɑn kəɾ əfɔɹɾ ivən wʌn pis ə kwəndɪlɝ.

And it was heartstone. The shopkeeper had never dared add that to what he thought were lies. No riverfront shopkeeper in Maradon could afford even one piece of cuendillar.

ðə dɪsk fɛl hɑɹɾ ən smuð ɪn ɪz hænd, ən nɑɾ əɾ ɔl væljəbəl ɪksɛp fəɹ ɪts eɪdʒ, bʌɾ i wɑz əfɹeɪɾ ɪt wɑz wʌɾ ɪz pɝsuɝz wɝ æftɝ. laɪtstɪks, ən aɪvɝi kɑɹvɪŋz, ən ivən boʊnz tɝn tə stoʊn, hi hæd sin ʌðɝ taɪmz, ʌðɝ pleɪsəz. jɛɾ ivən noʊɪŋ wʌt ðeɪ wɑntəd - ɪf i dɪd noʊ - hi stɪl hæd noʊ aɪdiə waɪ, ən i kəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ bi ʃʊɹ u hɪz pɝsuɝz wɝ. tɑɹ vəlɑn mɑɹks, ən ən eɪntʃən ɛɛs sədaɪ sɪmbəl. hi skɹʌbd ə hæn əkɹɔs ɪz lɪps; ðə teɪst ə fɪɹ leɪ bɪɾɝ ɑn ɪz tʌŋ.

The disk felt hard and smooth in his hand, and not at all valuable except for its age, but he was afraid it was what his pursuers were after. Lightsticks, and ivory carvings, and even bones turned to stone, he had seen other times, other places. Yet even knowing what they wanted - if he did know - he still had no idea why, and he could no longer be sure who his pursuers were. Tar Valon marks, and an ancient Aes Sedai symbol. He scrubbed a hand across his lips; the taste of fear lay bitter on his tongue.

ə nɑk ət ðə dɔɹ. hi sɛt ðə dɪsk daʊn ən pʊld ən ənɹoʊl tʃɑɹɾ oʊvɝ wʌt leɪ ɑn ɪz dɛsk. "kʌm."

A knock at the door. He set the disk down and pulled an unrolled chart over what lay on his desk. "Come."

jɑɹən ɛntɝd. "wɝ bɪɑn ðə bɹeɪkwɔɾɝ, kæptən."

Yarin entered. "We're beyond the breakwater, Captain."

doʊmən fɛlt ə flæʃ ə sɝpɹaɪz, ðən æŋɡɝ wɪð hɪmsɛlf. hi ʃəd nɛvɝ əv ɡɑɾən soʊ ɪnɡɹoʊs ðəɾ i feɪl tə fil spɹeɪ lɪftɪŋ ɑn ðə swɛlz. "meɪk wɛst, jɑɹən. si tə ɪt."

Domon felt a flash of surprise, then anger with himself. He should never have gotten so engrossed that he failed to feel Spray lifting on the swells. "Make west, Yarin. See to it."

"ɛbu dɑɹ, kæptən?"

"Ebou Dar, Captain?"

noʊ fɑɹ ɪnʌf. noʊ baɪ faɪv hʌnʒɹəd liɡz. "wil pʊɾ ɪn lɔŋ ɪnʌf fəɹ mi tə ɡɛt tʃɑɹts ən tɑp ðə wɔɾɝ bæɹəlz, ðən wi də seɪl wɛst."

No far enough. No by five hundred leagues. "We'll put in long enough for me to get charts and top the water barrels, then we do sail west."

"wɛst, kæptən? tʃɹɛmælkɪŋ? ðə si foʊk ɑɹ taɪt wɪð ɛni tʃɹeɪɾɝz bʌt ðɛɹ oʊn."

"West, Captain? Tremalking? The Sea Folk are tight with any traders but their own."

"ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən, jɑɹən. plɛnti ʌv tʃɹeɪd bɪtwin tæɹɑbən ən ɑɹæd dumən, ən hɑɹdli ə tæɹɑbənɝ əɹ dəmɑni bɑɾəm tə wɝi əbaʊt. ðeɪ də noʊ laɪk ðə si, aɪ hæv hɝd. ən ɔl ðoʊz smɔl taʊnz ɑn toʊmən hɛd, ɛvɹi wʌn hoʊldɪŋ ɪtsɛlf fɹi ʌv ɛni neɪʃən əɾ ɔl. wi kən ivən pɪk ʌp sɑldəiən fɝz ən aɪs pɛpɝz bɹɔt daʊn tə bændɑɹ ɛbən."

"The Aryth Ocean, Yarin. Plenty of trade between Tarabon and Arad Doman, and hardly a Taraboner or Domani bottom to worry about. They do no like the sea, I have heard. And all those small towns on Toman Head, every one holding itself free of any nation at all. We can even pick up Saldaean furs and ice peppers brought down to Bandar Eban."

jɑɹən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd sloʊli. hi ɔlweɪz lʊkt ət ðə dɑɹk saɪd, bʌɾ i wɑz ə ɡʊd seɪlɝ. "fɝz ən pɛpɝzəl kɑs mɔɹ ðəɹ ðən ɹʌnɪŋ ʌpɹɪvɝ fəɹ ðɛm, kæptən. ən aɪ hɪɹ ðɛɹz səm kaɪndə wɔɹ. ɪf tæɹɑbən ən ɑɹæd dumən ɑɹ faɪɾɪŋ, ðəɹ meɪ bi noʊ tʃɹeɪd. aɪ daʊt wɪl meɪk mʌtʃ ɔf ðə taʊnz ɑn toʊmən hɛɾ əloʊn, ivən ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹ seɪf. fɑlmz ðə lɑɹdʒəst, ən ɪts nɑt bɪɡ."

Yarin shook his head slowly. He always looked at the dark side, but he was a good sailor. "Furs and peppers'll cost more there than running upriver for them, Captain. And I hear there's some kind of war. If Tarabon and Arad Doman are fighting, there may be no trade. I doubt we'll make much off the towns on Toman Head alone, even if they are safe. Falme's the largest, and it is not big."

"ðə tæɹɑbənɝz ən ðə dəmɑni hæv ɔlweɪz skwɑbəld oʊvɝ ɑlməθ pleɪn ən toʊmən hɛd. ivən ɪf ɪts kʌm tə bloʊz ðɪs taɪm, ə kɛɹfəl mæn kən ɔlweɪz faɪn tʃɹeɪd. wɛst, jɑɹən."

"The Taraboners and the Domani have always squabbled over Almoth Plain and Toman Head. Even if it has come to blows this time, a careful man can always find trade. West, Yarin."

wən jɑɹən hæd ɡɔn tɑpsaɪd, doʊmən kwɪkli æɾəd ðə blæk-ænd-waɪt dɪsk tə ðə kʌbihoʊl, ən stoʊd ðə ɹɛs bæk ɪn ðə bɑɾəm ə hɪz tʃɛst. dɑɹkfɹɛnz əɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ, əl noʊ ɹʌn ðə weɪ ðeɪ wɑn mi. fɔɹtʃən pɹɪk mi, əl noʊ.

When Yarin had gone topside, Domon quickly added the black-and-white disk to the cubbyhole, and stowed the rest back in the bottom of his chest. Darkfriends or Aes Sedai, I'll no run the way they want me. Fortune prick me, I'll no.

filɪŋ seɪf fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm ɪn mʌnθs, doʊmən wɛn ɑn dɛk əz spɹeɪ hil tə kætʃ ðə wɪn ən pʊɾ əɹ baʊ wɛst ɪndə ðə naɪt-dɑɹk si.

Feeling safe for the first time in months, Domon went on deck as Spray heeled to catch the wind and put her bow west into the night-dark sea.


tʃæptɝ tɛn


CHAPTER 10

ðə hʌn bɪɡɪnz


The Hunt Begins

ɪŋtʃɹ sɛɾ ə fæs peɪs fəɹ ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ ʌv ə lɔŋ dʒɝni, fæst ɪnʌf ðət ɹænd wɝiɾ ə lɪɾəl əbaʊt ðə hɔɹsəz. ði ænəməlz kəd kip ʌp ðə tʃɹɑt fəɹ aʊɝz, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz stɪl moʊst ə ðə deɪ əhɛd, ən laɪkli deɪz mɔɹ bɪɑn ðæt. ðə weɪ ɪŋtʃɹz feɪs wɑz sɛt, ðoʊ, ɹænd θɔɾ i maɪɾ ɪntɛn tə kætʃ ðoʊz u hæd stoʊlən ðə hɔɹn ɪn ðə fɝs deɪ, ɪn ðə fɝst aʊɝ. ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ɪz vɔɪs wən i swɔɹ ɪz oʊθ tə ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, ɹænd wəd nɑɾ əv bɪn sɝpɹaɪzd. hi kɛpt ɪz maʊθ ʃʌt, ðoʊ. ɪt wɑz lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹz kəmænd; əz fɹɛnli əz i hæd bɪn tə ɹænd, hi stɪl wəd nɑɾ əpɹiʃieɪɾ ə ʃɛpɝd ɡɪvɪŋ ædvaɪs.

Ingtar set a fast pace for the beginning of a long journey, fast enough that Rand worried a little about the horses. The animals could keep up the trot for hours, but there was still most of the day ahead, and likely days more beyond that. The way Ingtar's face was set, though, Rand thought he might intend to catch those who had stolen the Horn in the first day, in the first hour. Remembering his voice when he swore his oath to the Amyrlin Seat, Rand would not have been surprised. He kept his mouth shut, though. It was Lord Ingtar's command; as friendly as he had been to Rand, he still would not appreciate a shepherd giving advice.

hʊɹɪn ɹoʊɾ ə peɪs bɪhaɪn ɪŋtʃɹ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðə snɪfɝ u lɛɾ əm saʊθ, pɔɪntɪŋ ðə weɪ fəɹ ɪŋtʃɹ. ðə lænd wɑz ɹoʊlɪŋ, fɔɹəstəd hɪlz, θɪk wɪð fɝ ən lɛðɝlif ən oʊk, bʌt ðə pæθ hʊɹɪn sɛt lɛɾ ɔlmoʊst stʃɹeɪɾ əz ən æɹoʊ, nɛvɝ weɪvɝɪŋ ɪksɛp tə ɡoʊ ɝaʊn ə fju ʌv ðə tɔlɝ hɪlz, wɛɹ ðə weɪ wɑz klɪɹli kwɪkɝ ɝaʊn ðən oʊvɝ. ðə ɡɹeɪ aʊl bænɝ ɹɪpəld ɪn ðə wɪnd.

Hurin rode a pace behind Ingtar, but it was the sniffer who led them south, pointing the way for Ingtar. The land was rolling, forested hills, thick with fir and leatherleaf and oak, but the path Hurin set led almost straight as an arrow, never wavering except to go around a few of the taller hills, where the way was clearly quicker around than over. The Gray Owl banner rippled in the wind.

ɹænd tʃɹaɪd tə ɹaɪd wɪð mæt ən pɛɹɪn, bʌt wən ɹænd lɛɾ ɪz hɔɹs dʒɹɑp bæk tə ðɛm, mæt nʌdʒ pɛɹɪn, ən pɛɹɪn ɹɪlʌktənli ɡæləp tə ðə hɛɾ ə ðə kɑləm wɪð mæt. tɛlɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɔɪn ɹaɪɾɪŋ ət ðə bæk baɪ hɪmsɛlf, ɹænd ɹoʊd bæk tə ðə fɹʌnt. ðeɪ fɛl tə ðə ɹɪɹ əɡɛn, mæt əɡɛn ɝdʒɪŋ pɛɹɪn.

Rand tried to ride with Mat and Perrin, but when Rand let his horse drop back to them, Mat nudged Perrin, and Perrin reluctantly galloped to the head of the column with Mat. Telling himself there was no point riding at the back by himself, Rand rode back to the front. They fell to the rear again, Mat again urging Perrin.

bɝn ðɛm. aɪ oʊnli wɑnə əpɑlədʒaɪz. hi fɛlt əloʊn. ɪt dɪd nɑt hɛlp ðəɾ i nu ɪt wɑz ɪz oʊn fɔlt.

Burn them. I only want to apologize. He felt alone. It did not help that he knew it was his own fault.

ətɑp wʌn hɪl, ənoʊ dɪsmaʊntɪd tə ɪɡzæmɪn ɡɹaʊn tʃɝn baɪ hʊvz. hi poʊkt ət səm hɔɹs dʒɹɑpɪŋz ən ɡɹʌntɪd. "blʌɾi wɛl muvɪŋ fæst, maɪ lɔɹd." hi hæɾ ə vɔɪs ðət saʊndəɾ əz ɪf i wɝ ʃaʊɾɪŋ wən i wɑz dʒʌst spikɪŋ. "wiv nɑt meɪɾ ʌp ən aʊɝ ɑn ðɛm. bɝn mi, wi meɪ hæv lɔst ə fleɪmɪŋ aʊɝ. ðəl kɪl ðɛɹ blʌɾi hɔɹsəz, ðə weɪ ðəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ." hi fɪŋɡɝɾ ə hʊf tʃɹæk. "noʊ hɔɹs, ðæt. blʌɾi tʃɹɑlɑk. səm fleɪmɪŋ ɡoʊt fiɾ oʊvɝ ðɛɹ."

Atop one hill, Uno dismounted to examine ground churned by hooves. He poked at some horse droppings and grunted. "Bloody well moving fast, my Lord." He had a voice that sounded as if he were shouting when he was just speaking. "We've not made up an hour on them. Burn me, we may have lost a flaming hour. They'll kill their bloody horses, the way they're going." He fingered a hoofed track. "No horse, that. Bloody Trolloc. Some flaming goat feet over there."

"wi wɪl kætʃ ðɛm," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd ɡɹɪmli.

"We will catch them," Ingtar said grimly.

"aʊɝ hɔɹsəz, maɪ lɔɹd. dʌz noʊ ɡʊd tə ɹaɪɾ əm ɪndə ðə blʌɾi ɡɹaʊn bɪfɔɹ wi də kætʃ ʌp, maɪ lɔɹd. ivən ɪf ðeɪ də kɪl ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz, blʌɾi tʃɹɑləks kən kip ɡoʊɪŋ lɔŋɡɝ ðən hɔɹsəz."

"Our horses, my Lord. Does no good to ride them into the bloody ground before we do catch up, my Lord. Even if they do kill their horses, bloody Trollocs can keep going longer than horses."

"wi wɪl kætʃ ðɛm. maʊnt, ənoʊ."

"We will catch them. Mount, Uno."

ənoʊ lʊkt ət ɹænd wɪð ɪz wʌn aɪ, ðən ʃɹʌɡd ən klaɪmd ɪndə hɪz sæɾəl. ɪŋtʃɹ tʊk əm daʊn ðə fɑɹ sloʊp əɾ ə ɹʌn, hæf slaɪɾɪŋ ɔl ðə weɪ tə ðə bɑɾəm, ən ɡæləpt ʌp ðə nɛkst.

Uno looked at Rand with his one eye, then shrugged and climbed into his saddle. Ingtar took them down the far slope at a run, half sliding all the way to the bottom, and galloped up the next.

waɪ dɪɾ i lʊk ət mi ðət weɪ, ɹænd wʌndɝd. ənoʊ wɑz wʌn ə ðoʊz u hæd nɛvɝ ʃoʊn mʌtʃ fɹɛnlinɪs təwɔɹd hɪm. ɪt wɑz nɑt laɪk mæsiməz oʊpən dɪslaɪk; ənoʊ wɑz nɑt fɹɛnli wɪð ɛniwʌn ɪksɛpt ə fju vɛɾɝənz əz ɡɹɪzəld əz hɪmsɛlf. ʃʊɹli hi dʌzn bɪliv ðət teɪl əbaʊt mi biɪŋ ə lɔɹd.

Why did he look at me that way, Rand wondered. Uno was one of those who had never shown much friendliness toward him. It was not like Masema's open dislike; Uno was not friendly with anyone except a few veterans as grizzled as himself. Surely he doesn't believe that tale about me being a lord.

ənoʊ spɛn ɪz taɪm stʌɾiɪŋ ðə kʌntʃɹi əhɛd, bʌt wən i kɑt ɹænd lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm, hi ɡeɪv bæk stɛɹ fəɹ stɛɹ, ən nɛvɝ sɛɾ ə wɝd. ɪt dɪd nɑt min mʌtʃ. hi wəd stɛɹ ɪŋtʃɹ ɪn ði aɪ, tu. ðət wɑz ənoʊz weɪ.

Uno spent his time studying the country ahead, but when he caught Rand looking at him, he gave back stare for stare, and never said a word. It did not mean much. He would stare Ingtar in the eye, too. That was Uno's way.

ðə pæθ tʃoʊzən baɪ ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz - ən wʌɾ ɛls, ɹænd wʌndɝd; hʊɹɪn kɛp mʌɾɝɪŋ əbaʊt "sʌmθɪŋ wɝs" - hu hæd stoʊlən ðə hɔɹn nɛvɝ keɪm kloʊs tə ɛni vɪlədʒ. ɹænd sɔ vɪlədʒəz, fɹəm wʌn hɪltɑp tə ənʌðɝ, wɪð ə maɪl əɹ mɔɹ ʌv ʌp-ænd-daʊn kʌntʃɹi bɪtwin, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz nɛvɝ wʌn kloʊs ɪnʌf tə meɪk aʊt ðə pipəl ɪn ðə stʃɹits. əɹ kloʊs ɪnʌf fəɹ ðoʊz pipəl tə meɪk aʊɾ ə pɑɹɾi hɛɾɪŋ saʊθ. ðəɹ wɝ fɑɹmz, tu, wɪð loʊ-iv haʊsəz ən tɔl bɑɹnz ən smoʊkɪŋ tʃɪmniz, ɑn hɪltɑps ən ɑn hɪlsaɪdz ən ɪn ðə bɑɾəmz, bʌt nɛvɝ wʌn kloʊs ɪnʌf fəɹ ðə fɑɹmɝ tə hæv sin ðɛɹ kwɔɹi.

The path chosen by the Darkfriends - And what else, Rand wondered; Hurin kept muttering about "something worse" - who had stolen the Horn never came close to any village. Rand saw villages, from one hilltop to another, with a mile or more of up-and-down country between, but there was never one close enough to make out the people in the streets. Or close enough for those people to make out a party heading south. There were farms, too, with low-eaved houses and tall barns and smoking chimneys, on hilltops and on hillsides and in the bottoms, but never one close enough for the farmer to have seen their quarry.

ɪvɛntʃəwəli ivən ɪŋtʃɹ hæd tə ɹilaɪz ðət ðə hɔɹsəz kəd nɑt kip ɑn əz ðeɪ wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ. ɹænd hɝd mʌɾɝd kɝsɪz, ən ɪŋtʃɹ paʊndɪɾ ɪz θaɪ wɪð ə ɡɔntələɾəd fɪst, bʌt faɪnəli hi ɔɹɾɝd ɛvɹiwʌn tə dɪsmaʊnt. ðeɪ tʃɹɑɾəd, liɾɪŋ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz, ʌphɪl ən daʊn, fəɹ ə maɪl, ðən maʊntəɾ ən ɹoʊɾ əɡɛn. ðən ɪt wɑz daʊn əɡɛn ən tʃɹɑt. tʃɹɑɾ ə maɪl, ðən ɹaɪɾ ə maɪl. tʃɹɑt, ðən ɹaɪd.

Eventually even Ingtar had to realize that the horses could not keep on as they were going. Rand heard muttered curses, and Ingtar pounded his thigh with a gauntleted fist, but finally he ordered everyone to dismount. They trotted, leading their horses, uphill and down, for a mile, then mounted and rode again. Then it was down again and trot. Trot a mile, then ride a mile. Trot, then ride.

ɹænd wɑz sɝpɹaɪz tə si lɔɪəl ɡɹɪnɪŋ wən ðeɪ wɝ daʊn ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, tɔɪlɪŋ ʌp ə hɪl. ði oʊɡiɝ hæd bɪn ənizi əbaʊt ɹaɪɾɪŋ ən hɔɹsəz wən ðeɪ fɝs mɛt, pɹɪfɝɪŋ tə tʃɹʌs tə hɪz oʊn fit, bʌt ɹænd θɔɾ i hæd lɔŋ ɡɑɾən oʊvɝ ðæt.

Rand was surprised to see Loial grinning when they were down on the ground, toiling up a hill. The Ogier had been uneasy about riding and horses when they first met, preferring to trust to his own feet, but Rand thought he had long gotten over that.

"du jə laɪk tə ɹʌn, ɹænd?" lɔɪəl læft. "aɪ du. aɪ wɑz ðə fæstəst ɪn stɛɾɪŋ ʃæŋktaɪ. aɪ aʊtʃɹæn ə hɔɹs, wʌns."

"Do you like to run, Rand?" Loial laughed. "I do. I was the fastest in Stedding Shangtai. I outran a horse, once."

ɹænd oʊnli ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə weɪs bɹɛθ ɑn tɔk. hi lʊk fəɹ mæt ən pɛɹɪn, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ stɪl ət ðə bæk, tu mɛni mɛn bɪtwin fəɹ ɹænd tə meɪk əm aʊt. hi wʌndɝd haʊ ðə ʃaɪnɝənz kəd mænədʒ ðɪs ɪn ðɛɹ ɑɹmɝ. nɑɾ ə wʌn ə ðɛm sloʊɾ əɹ vɔɪst ə kəmpleɪnt. ənoʊ dɪd nɑɾ ivən lʊk əz ɪf i wɝ bɹeɪkɪŋ ə swɛt, ən ðə bænɝmən nɛvɝ lɛt ðə ɡɹeɪ aʊl weɪvɝ.

Rand only shook his head. He did not want to waste breath on talk. He looked for Mat and Perrin, but they were still at the back, too many men between for Rand to make them out. He wondered how the Shienarans could manage this in their armor. Not a one of them slowed or voiced a complaint. Uno did not even look as if he were breaking a sweat, and the bannerman never let the Gray Owl waver.

ɪt wɑz ə kwɪk peɪs, bʌt twaɪlaɪt bɪɡæn tə kloʊz wɪθaʊɾ ɛni saɪɾ ə ðoʊz ðeɪ hʌntəɾ ɪksɛp ðɛɹ tʃɹæks. ət læst, ɹɪlʌktənli, ɪŋtʃɹ kɔld ə hɔl tə meɪk kæmp fəɹ ðə naɪɾ ɪn ðə fɔɹəst. ðə ʃaɪnɝənz wɛn əbaʊt ɡɛɾɪŋ faɪɝz stɑɹɾəd ən sɛɾɪŋ pɪkət-laɪnz fəɹ ðə hɔɹsəz wɪð ə smuð ɪkɑnəmi ʌv ɛfɝt bɔɹn ə lɔŋ ɪkspɪɹiəns. ɪŋtʃɹ poʊstɪd sɪks ɡɑɹdz, ɪn pɛɹz, fəɹ ðə fɝst wɑtʃ.

It was a quick pace, but twilight began to close without any sight of those they hunted except their tracks. At last, reluctantly, Ingtar called a halt to make camp for the night in the forest. The Shienarans went about getting fires started and setting picket-lines for the horses with a smooth economy of effort born of long experience. Ingtar posted six guards, in pairs, for the first watch.

ɹændz fɝst ɔɹɾɝ ə bɪznəs wɑz faɪndɪŋ ɪz bʌndəl ɪn ðə wɪkɝ pænɪɝz fɹəm ðə pækhɔɹsɪz. ɪt wɑz nɑt hɑɹd - ðəɹ wɝ fju pɝsənəl bʌndəlz əmʌŋ ðə səplaɪz - bʌt wən i hæɾ ɪɾ oʊpən, hi lɛɾ aʊɾ ə ʃaʊt ðət bɹɔɾ ɛvɹi mæn ɪn ðə kæmp ɪɹɛkt wɪð sɔɹɾ ɪn hænd.

Rand's first order of business was finding his bundle in the wicker panniers from the packhorses. It was not hard - there were few personal bundles among the supplies - but when he had it open, he let out a shout that brought every man in the camp erect with sword in hand.

ɪŋtʃɹ keɪm ɹʌnɪŋ. "wʌɾ ɪz ɪt? pis, dɪd sʌmwʌn ɡɛt θɹu? aɪ dɪd nɑt hɪɹ ðə ɡɑɹdz."

Ingtar came running. "What is it? Peace, did someone get through? I did not hear the guards."

"ɪts ðiz koʊts," ɹænd ɡɹaʊld, stɪl stɛɹɪŋ ət wʌɾ i hæɾ ənpækt. wʌn koʊt wɑz blæk, ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð sɪlvɝ θɹɛd, ði ʌðɝ waɪt wɝkt ɪn ɡoʊld. boʊθ hæd hɛɹənz ɑn ðə kɑlɝz, ən boʊθ wɝ ət list əz ɔɹneɪɾ əz ðə skɑɹlət koʊɾ i wɑz wɛɹɪŋ. "ðə sɝvəns toʊl mi aɪ hæd tu ɡʊd, sɝvəsəbəl koʊts ɪn hɪɹ. lʊk ət ðɛm!"

"It's these coats," Rand growled, still staring at what he had unpacked. One coat was black, embroidered with silver thread, the other white worked in gold. Both had herons on the collars, and both were at least as ornate as the scarlet coat he was wearing. "The servants told me I had two good, serviceable coats in here. Look at them!"

ɪŋtʃɹ ʃiðd ɪz sɔɹɾ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. ði ʌðɝ mɛn bɪɡæn tə sɛɾəl bæk daʊn. "wɛl, ðeɪ ɑɹ sɝvəsəbəl."

Ingtar sheathed his sword over his shoulder. The other men began to settle back down. "Well, they are serviceable."

"aɪ kænt wɛɹ ðiz. aɪ kænt ɡoʊ ɝaʊn dʒɹɛs laɪk ðɪs ɔl ðə taɪm."

"I can't wear these. I can't go around dressed like this all the time."

"ju kən wɛɹ ðɛm. ə koʊts ə koʊt. aɪ ʌndɝstæn mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ hɝsɛlf sɔ tə jəɹ pækɪŋ. meɪbi ɛɛs sədaɪ də nɑɾ ɪɡzækli ʌndɝstænd wʌɾ ə mæn wɛɹz ɪn ðə fild." ɪŋtʃɹ ɡɹɪnd. "æftɝ wi kætʃ ðiz tʃɹɑləks, pɝhæps wɪl əv ə fist. jəl bi dʒɹɛs fəɹ ɪt, ət list, ivən ɪf ðə ɹɛst ʌv əs ɑɹ nɑt." hi stʃɹoʊl bæk tə wɛɹ ðə kʊk faɪɝz wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi bɝnɪŋ.

"You can wear them. A coat's a coat. I understand Moiraine Sedai herself saw to your packing. Maybe Aes Sedai do not exactly understand what a man wears in the field." Ingtar grinned. "After we catch these Trollocs, perhaps we'll have a feast. You will be dressed for it, at least, even if the rest of us are not." He strolled back to where the cook fires were already burning.

ɹænd hæd nɑt muv sɪns ɪŋtʃɹ mɛnʃən mɔɪɹeɪn. hi stɛɹɾ ət ðə koʊts. wʌɾ ɪz ʃi duɪŋ? wʌtɛvɝ ɪɾ ɪz, əl nɑt bi juzd. hi bʌndəld ɛvɹiθɪŋ təɡɛðɝ əɡɛn ən stʌf ðə bʌndəl bæk ɪndə ðə pæniɝ. aɪ kən ɔlweɪz ɡoʊ neɪkəd, hi θɔt bɪɾɝli.

Rand had not moved since Ingtar mentioned Moiraine. He stared at the coats. What is she doing? Whatever it is, I will not be used. He bundled everything together again and stuffed the bundle back into the pannier. I can always go naked, he thought bitterly.

ʃaɪnɝənz tʊk tɝnz ət ðə kʊkɪŋ wən ðeɪ wɝ ɪn ðə fild, ən mæsimə wɑz stɝɪŋ ðə kɛɾəl wən ɹænd ɹɪtɝn tə ðə faɪɝz. ðə smɛl ʌv ə stu meɪd fɹəm tɝnəps, ʌnjənz, ən dʒɹaɪd mit sɛɾəld oʊvɝ ðə kæmp. ɪŋtʃɹ wɑz sɝv fɝst, ən ðən ənoʊ, bʌɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls stʊɾ ɪn laɪn haʊɛvɝ ðeɪ hæpən tə kʌm. mæsimə slɑpt ə bɪɡ leɪɾəl ə stu ɑn ɹændz pleɪt; ɹænd stɛp bæk kwɪkli tə kip fɹəm ɡɛɾɪŋ ði oʊvɝfloʊ ɑn ɪz koʊt, ən meɪd ɹum fəɹ ðə nɛks mæn waɪl sʌkɪŋ ə bɝn θʌm. mæsimə stɛɹɾ ət hɪm, wɪð ə fɪkst ɡɹɪn ðət nɛvɝ ɹitʃt ɪz aɪz. əntɪl ənoʊ stɛpt ʌp ən kʌf hɪm.

Shienarans took turns at the cooking when they were in the field, and Masema was stirring the kettle when Rand returned to the fires. The smell of a stew made from turnips, onions, and dried meat settled over the camp. Ingtar was served first, and then Uno, but everyone else stood in line however they happened to come. Masema slopped a big ladle of stew on Rand's plate; Rand stepped back quickly to keep from getting the overflow on his coat, and made room for the next man while sucking a burned thumb. Masema stared at him, with a fixed grin that never reached his eyes. Until Uno stepped up and cuffed him.

"wi dɪdn blʌɾi bɹɪŋ ɪnʌf fəɹ jə tə bi spɪlɪŋ ɪɾ ɑn ðə fleɪmɪŋ ɡɹaʊnd." ðə wʌn-aɪd mæn lʊkt ət ɹænd ən lɛft. mæsimə ɹʌbd ɪz ɪɹ, bʌɾ ɪz ɡlɛɹ fɑloʊd ɹænd.

"We didn't bloody bring enough for you to be spilling it on the flaming ground." The one-eyed man looked at Rand and left. Masema rubbed his ear, but his glare followed Rand.

ɹænd wɛn tə dʒɔɪn ɪŋtʃɹ ən lɔɪəl, sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn ʌndɝ ə spɹɛɾɪŋ oʊk. ɪŋtʃɹ hæɾ ɪz hɛlməɾ ɔf, ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪsaɪd hɪm, bʌɾ ʌðɝwaɪz i wɑz fʊli ɑɹmɝd. mæt ən pɛɹɪn wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi ðɛɹ, iɾɪŋ hʌŋɡɹəli. mæt ɡeɪv ə bɹɔd snɪɹ ət ɹændz koʊt, bʌt pɛɹɪn bɛɹli lʊkt ʌp, ɡoʊldən aɪz ʃaɪnɪŋ ɪn ðə hæf-laɪt fɹəm ðə faɪɝz, bɪfɔɹ bɛndɪŋ bæk tə hɪz pleɪt.

Rand went to join Ingtar and Loial, sitting on the ground under a spreading oak. Ingtar had his helmet off, on the ground beside him, but otherwise he was fully armored. Mat and Perrin were already there, eating hungrily. Mat gave a broad sneer at Rand's coat, but Perrin barely looked up, golden eyes shining in the half-light from the fires, before bending back to his plate.

ət lis ðeɪ dɪdn liv ðɪs taɪm.

At least they didn't leave this time.

hi sæt kɹɔs-lɛɡəɾ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ʌv ɪŋtʃɹ fɹəm ðɛm. "aɪ wɪʃ aɪ nu waɪ ənoʊ kips lʊkɪŋ ət mi. ɪts pɹɑbli ðɪs blʌɾi koʊt."

He sat cross-legged on the other side of Ingtar from them. "I wish I knew why Uno keeps looking at me. It's probably this bloody coat."

ɪŋtʃɹ pɔz θɔtfəli ɝaʊn ə maʊθfʊl ə stu. faɪnəli hi sɛd, "ənoʊ noʊ daʊt wʌndɝz ɪf jə ɑɹ wɝði ʌv ə hɛɹən-mɑɹk bleɪd." mæt snɔɹɾɪd laʊdli, bʌɾ ɪŋtʃɹ wɛn ɑn ʌnpɝtɝbd. "du nɑt lɛɾ ənoʊ ʌpsɛt ju. hi wəd tʃɹit lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ laɪk ə ɹɔ ɹəkɹuɾ ɪf i kʊd. wɛl, pɝhæps nɑɾ eɪɡəlmɝ, bʌɾ ɛniwʌn ɛls. hiz ə tʌŋ laɪk ə faɪl, bʌɾ i ɡɪvz ɡʊɾ ædvaɪs. hi ʃʊd; hiz bɪn kæmpeɪnɪŋ sɪns bɪfɔɹ aɪ wɑz bɔɹn. lɪsən tə hɪz ædvaɪs, doʊn maɪn ɪz tʌŋ, ən jəl də ɔl ɹaɪt wɪð ənoʊ."

Ingtar paused thoughtfully around a mouthful of stew. Finally he said, "Uno no doubt wonders if you are worthy of a heron-mark blade." Mat snorted loudly, but Ingtar went on unperturbed. "Do not let Uno upset you. He would treat Lord Agelmar like a raw recruit if he could. Well, perhaps not Agelmar, but anyone else. He has a tongue like a file, but he gives good advice. He should; he's been campaigning since before I was born. Listen to his advice, don't mind his tongue, and you will do all right with Uno."

"aɪ θɔɾ i wɑz laɪk mæsimə." ɹænd ʃʌvəl stu ɪndə hɪz maʊð. ɪt wɑz tu hɑt, bʌɾ i ɡʌlpt ɪt daʊn. ðeɪ hæd nɑɾ iɾən sɪns livɪŋ fæl dæɹə, ən i hæd bɪn tu wɝid tə it ðət mɔɹnɪŋ. hɪz stʌmək ɹʌmbəld, ɹimaɪndɪŋ ɪm ɪt wɑz pæs taɪm. hi wʌndɝɾ ɪf tɛlɪŋ mæsimə hi laɪk ðə fud wəd hɛlp. "mæsimə æks laɪk i heɪts mi, ən aɪ doʊn ʌndɝstæn ɪt."

"I thought he was like Masema." Rand shoveled stew into his mouth. It was too hot, but he gulped it down. They had not eaten since leaving Fal Dara, and he had been too worried to eat that morning. His stomach rumbled, reminding him it was past time. He wondered if telling Masema he liked the food would help. "Masema acts like he hates me, and I don't understand it."

"mæsimə sɝv θɹi jɪɹz ɪn ði istɝn mɑɹtʃɪz," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd. "æɾ ɑŋkɝ deɪl, əɡɛns ði il." hi stɝɾ ɪz stu wɪð ɪz spun, fɹaʊnɪŋ. "aɪ æsk noʊ kwɛstʃənz, maɪnd. ɪf læn daɪ ʃæn ən mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ wɑnə seɪ jə ɑɹ fɹəm ændɝ, fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, ðən jə ɑɹ. bʌt mæsimə kænt ɡɛt ðə lʊk ə ði il aʊɾ ə hɪz hɛd, ən wən i siz ju. . . ." hi ʃɹʌɡd. "aɪ æsk noʊ kwɛstʃənz."

"Masema served three years in the Eastern Marches," Ingtar said. "At Ankor Dail, against the Aiel." He stirred his stew with his spoon, frowning. "I ask no questions, mind. If Lan Dai Shan and Moiraine Sedai want to say you are from Andor, from the Two Rivers, then you are. But Masema can't get the look of the Aiel out of his head, and when he sees you. . . ." He shrugged. "I ask no questions."

ɹænd dʒɹɑpt ɪz spun ɪn ðə pleɪt wɪð ə saɪ. "ɛvɹibɑɾi θɪŋks aɪm sʌmbɑɾi aɪm nɑt. aɪm fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, ɪŋtʃɹ. aɪ ɡɹu təbæk wɪð - wɪð maɪ fɑðɝ, ən tɛndəɾ ɪz ʃip. ðəɾ ɪz wʌɾ aɪ æm. ə fɑɹmɝ ən ʃɛpɝd fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz."

Rand dropped his spoon in the plate with a sigh. "Everybody thinks I'm somebody I am not. I am from the Two Rivers, Ingtar. I grew tabac with - with my father, and tended his sheep. That is what I am. A farmer and shepherd from the Two Rivers."

"hiz fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz," mæt sɛd skɔɹnfəli. "aɪ ɡɹu ʌp wɪð hɪm, ðoʊ jud nɛvɝ noʊ ɪt naʊ. jə pʊt ðɪs il nɑnsɛns ɪn ɪz hɛɾ ɑn tɑp ʌv wʌts ɔlɹɛɾi ðɛɹ, ən ðə laɪt noʊz wʌt wɪl hæv. ən il lɔɹd, meɪbi."

"He's from the Two Rivers," Mat said scornfully. "I grew up with him, though you'd never know it now. You put this Aiel nonsense in his head on top of what's already there, and the Light knows what we'll have. An Aiel lord, maybe."

"noʊ," lɔɪəl sɛd, "hi hæz ðə lʊk. jə ɹɪmɛmbɝ, ɹænd, aɪ ɹɪmɑɹkt ɑn ɪt wʌns, ðoʊ aɪ θɔɾ ɪt wɑz dʒʌs kəz aɪ dɪdnt noʊ jə hjumənz wɛl ɪnʌf ðɛn. ɹɪmɛmbɝ? 'tɪl ʃeɪɾ ɪz ɡɔn, tɪl wɔɾɝ ɪz ɡɔn, ɪndə ðə ʃædoʊ wɪð tiθ bɛɹd, skɹimɪŋ dɪfaɪəns wɪð ðə læs bɹɛθ, tə spɪɾ ɪn saɪtblɪndɝz aɪ ɑn ðə læs deɪ.' jə ɹɪmɛmbɝ, ɹænd."

"No," Loial said, "he has the look. You remember, Rand, I remarked on it once, though I thought it was just because I didn't know you humans well enough then. Remember? 'Till shade is gone, till water is gone, into the Shadow with teeth bared, screaming defiance with the last breath, to spit in Sightblinder's eye on the Last Day.' You remember, Rand."

ɹænd stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪz pleɪt. ɹæp ə ʃoʊufə ɝaʊn jəɹ hɛd, ən jə wəd bi ði ɪmədʒ ʌv ən ilmən. ðət hæd bɪn ɡɔɪn, bɹʌðɝ tə ɪleɪn, ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ʌv ændɝ. ɛvɹibɑɾi θɪŋks aɪm sʌmbɑɾi aɪm nɑt.

Rand stared at his plate. Wrap a shoufa around your head, and you would be the image of an Aielman. That had been Gawyn, brother to Elayne, the Daughter-Heir of Andor. Everybody thinks I'm somebody I'm not.

"wʌt wɑz ðæt?" mæt æskt. "əbaʊt spɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə dɑɹk wʌnz aɪ."

"What was that?" Mat asked. "About spitting in the Dark One's eye."

"ðæts haʊ lɔŋ ði il seɪ ðəl faɪt," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd, "æn aɪ doʊn daʊt ðeɪ wɪl. ɪksɛp fəɹ pɛdlɝz ən ɡlimən, il dɪvaɪd ðə wɝld ɪn tu. il, ən ɛnəmiz. ðeɪ tʃeɪnʒd ðət fəɹ kɛɹhin faɪv hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz əɡoʊ, fəɹ səm ɹizən noʊ wʌn bʌɾ ən il kəɾ ʌndɝstænd, bʌɾ aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk ðəl ɛvɝ də soʊ əɡɛn."

"That's how long the Aiel say they'll fight," Ingtar said, "and I don't doubt they will. Except for peddlers and gleemen, Aiel divide the world in two. Aiel, and enemies. They changed that for Cairhien five hundred years ago, for some reason no one but an Aiel could understand, but I do not think they will ever do so again."

"aɪ səpoʊz nɑt," lɔɪəl saɪd. "bʌt ðeɪ də lɛt ðə tuætɑn, ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ pipəl, kɹɔs ðə weɪst. ən ðeɪ doʊn si oʊɡiɝ əz ɛnəmiz, iðɝ, ðoʊ aɪ daʊɾ ɛni ʌv əs wəd wɑnə ɡoʊ aʊɾ ɪndə ðə weɪst. il kʌm tə stɛɾɪŋ ʃæŋktaɪ səmtaɪmz tə tʃɹeɪd fəɹ sʌŋ wʊd. ə hɑɹd pipəl, ðoʊ."

"I suppose not," Loial sighed. "But they do let the Tuatha'an, the Traveling People, cross the Waste. And they don't see Ogier as enemies, either, though I doubt any of us would want to go out into the Waste. Aiel come to Stedding Shangtai sometimes to trade for sung wood. A hard people, though."

ɪŋtʃɹ nɑɾəd. "aɪ wɪʃ aɪ hæd səm əz hɑɹd. hæf əz hɑɹd."

Ingtar nodded. "I wish I had some as hard. Half as hard."

"ɪz ðəɾ ə dʒoʊk?" mæt læft. "ɪf aɪ ɹæn ə maɪl wɛɹɪŋ ɔl ði aɪɝn jəɹ wɛɹɪŋ, aɪ wəd fɔl daʊn ən slip ə wik. juv dʌn ɪt maɪl æftɝ maɪl ɔl deɪ."

"Is that a joke?" Mat laughed. "If I ran a mile wearing all the iron you're wearing, I would fall down and sleep a week. You've done it mile after mile all day."

"il ɑɹ hɑɹd," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd.
