"mæn ən wʊmən, hɑɹd. aɪv fɔt ðɛm, ən aɪ noʊ. ðəl ɹʌn fɪfti maɪlz, ən faɪɾ ə bæɾəl ət ði ɛn ʌv ɪt. ðəɹ dɛθ wɔkɪŋ, wɪð ɛni wɛpən əɹ nʌn. ɪksɛpt ə sɔɹd. ðəl nɑt tʌtʃ ə sɔɹd, fəɹ səm ɹizən. əɹ ɹaɪɾ ə hɔɹs, nɑt ðət ðeɪ nid tə. ɪf juv ə sɔɹd, ən ði ilmən əz ɪz bɛɹ hænz, ɪts ən ivən faɪt. ɪf jəɹ ɡʊd. ðeɪ hɝd kæɾəl ən ɡoʊts wɛɹ jə əɹ aɪ wəd daɪ ʌv θɝs bɪfɔɹ ðə deɪ wɑz dʌn. ðeɪ dɪɡ ðɛɹ vɪlədʒəz ɪndə hjudʒ ɹɑk spaɪɹz aʊɾ ɪn ðə weɪst. ðeɪv bɪn ðəɹ sɪns ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ, nɪɹ ɪnʌf. ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ tʃɹaɪd tə dɪɡ ðɛm aʊɾ ən wɑz blʌɾid, ði oʊnli meɪdʒɝ dɪfits i ɛvɝ sʌfɝd. baɪ deɪ ði ɛɹ ɪn ði il weɪst ʃɪmɝz wɪð hit, ən baɪ naɪɾ ɪt fɹizɪz. ən ən il wɪl ɡɪv jə ðət blu-aɪd stɛɹ ən tɛl jə ðəɹ ɪz noʊ pleɪs ɑn ɝθ i wəd ɹæðɝ bi. hi woʊn bi laɪɪŋ, iðɝ. ɪf ðeɪ ɛvɝ tʃɹaɪd tə kʌm aʊt, wi wəd bi hɑɹd-pɹɛs tə stɑp ðɛm. ði il wɔɹ læstəd θɹi jɪɹz, ən ðət wɑz oʊnli fɔɹ aʊɾ ə θɝtin klænz."

"Aiel are hard," Ingtar said. "Man and woman, hard. I've fought them, and I know. They will run fifty miles, and fight a battle at the end of it. They're death walking, with any weapon or none. Except a sword. They will not touch a sword, for some reason. Or ride a horse, not that they need to. If you have a sword, and the Aielman has his bare hands, it is an even fight. If you're good. They herd cattle and goats where you or I would die of thirst before the day was done. They dig their villages into huge rock spires out in the Waste. They've been there since the Breaking, near enough. Artur Hawkwing tried to dig them out and was bloodied, the only major defeats he ever suffered. By day the air in the Aiel Waste shimmers with heat, and by night it freezes. And an Aiel will give you that blue-eyed stare and tell you there is no place on earth he would rather be. He won't be lying, either. If they ever tried to come out, we would be hard-pressed to stop them. The Aiel War lasted three years, and that was only four out of thirteen clans."

"ɡɹeɪ aɪz fɹəm ɪz mʌðɝ dʌzn meɪk ɪm ən il," mæt sɛd.

"Gray eyes from his mother doesn't make him an Aiel," Mat said.

ɪŋtʃɹ ʃɹʌɡd. "æz aɪ sɛd, aɪ æsk noʊ kwɛstʃənz."

Ingtar shrugged. "As I said, I ask no questions."

wən ɹænd faɪnəli sɛɾəld daʊn fəɹ ðə naɪt, hɪz hɛd hʌmd wɪð ənwɔntɪd θɔts. ɪmədʒ ʌv ən ilmən. mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ wɑns tə seɪ jəɹ fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. il ɹævɪdʒd ɔl ðə weɪ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn. bɔɹn ɑn ðə sloʊps ə dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt. ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn.

When Rand finally settled down for the night, his head hummed with unwanted thoughts. Image of an Aielman. Moiraine Sedai wants to say you're from the Two Rivers. Aiel ravaged all the way to Tar Valon. Born on the slopes of Dragonmount. The Dragon Reborn.

"aɪ wɪl nɑt bi juzd," hi mʌɾɝd, bʌt slip wɑz ə lɔŋ taɪm kʌmɪŋ.

"I will not be used," he muttered, but sleep was a long time coming.

ɪŋtʃɹ bɹoʊk kæmp bɪfɔɹ ðə sʌn wɑz ʌp ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ. ðeɪ hæd bɹɛkfæstəɾ ən wɝ ɹaɪɾɪŋ saʊθ waɪl ðə klaʊdz ɪn ði ist wɝ stɪl ɹɛd wɪð sʌnɹaɪz tə kʌm ən du stɪl hʌŋ ɑn ðə livz. ðɪs taɪm ɪŋtʃɹ pʊɾ aʊt skaʊts, ən ðoʊ ðə peɪs wɑz hɑɹd, ɪt wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ hɔɹs-kɪlɪŋ. ɹænd θɔt meɪbi ɪŋtʃɹ hæd ɹilaɪz ðeɪ wɝ nɑt gɑnə də ɪɾ ɔl ɪn ə deɪ. ðə tʃɹeɪl stɪl lɛd saʊθ, hʊɹɪn sɛd. əntɪl, tu aʊɝz æftɝ ðə sʌn ɹoʊz, wʌn ə ðə skaʊts keɪm ɡæləpɪŋ bæk.

Ingtar broke camp before the sun was up in the morning. They had breakfasted and were riding south while the clouds in the east were still red with sunrise to come and dew still hung on the leaves. This time Ingtar put out scouts, and though the pace was hard, it was no longer horse-killing. Rand thought maybe Ingtar had realized they were not going to do it all in a day. The trail still led south, Hurin said. Until, two hours after the sun rose, one of the scouts came galloping back.

"əbændən kæmp əhɛd, maɪ lɔɹd. dʒʌst ɑn ðət hɪltɑp ðɛɹ. mʌst əv bɪn ət lis θɝɾi əɹ fɔɹɾi ʌv əm ðəɹ læs naɪt, maɪ lɔɹd."

"Abandoned camp ahead, my Lord. Just on that hilltop there. Must have been at least thirty or forty of them there last night, my Lord."

ɪŋtʃɹ pʊt spɝz tə hɔɹs əz ɪf i hæd bɪn toʊl ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz wɝ stɪl ðɛɹ, ən ɹænd hæd tə kip peɪs əɹ bi tʃɹæmpəl baɪ ðə ʃaɪnɝənz u ɡæləpt ʌp ðə hɪl bɪhaɪn hɪm.

Ingtar put spurs to horse as if he had been told the Darkfriends were still there, and Rand had to keep pace or be trampled by the Shienarans who galloped up the hill behind him.

ðəɹ wɑz nɑt mʌtʃ tə si. ðə koʊld æʃəz ə kæmpfaɪɝz, wɛl hɪɾən ɪn ðə tʃɹiz, wɪð wʌt lʊk laɪk ðə ɹɛmnəns ʌv ə mil tɔst ɪn ðɛm. ə ɹɛfjus hip tu nɪɹ ðə faɪɝz ən ɔlɹɛɾi bʌzɪŋ wɪð flaɪz.

There was not much to see. The cold ashes of campfires, well hidden in the trees, with what looked like the remnants of a meal tossed in them. A refuse heap too near the fires and already buzzing with flies.

ɪŋtʃɹ kɛp ði ʌðɝz bæk, ən dɪsmaʊntɪd tə wɔk θɹu ðə kæmpsaɪt wɪð ənoʊ, ɪɡzæmɪnɪŋ ðə ɡɹaʊnd. hʊɹɪn ɹoʊd ðə sɝkʌmfɹəns ə ðə saɪt, snɪfɪŋ. ɹænd sæɾ ɪz stæljən wɪð ði ʌðɝ mɛn; hi hæd noʊ dɪzaɪɝ fəɹ ɛni kloʊsɝ lʊk əɾ ə pleɪs wɛɹ tʃɹɑləks ən dɑɹkfɹɛnz hæd kæmpt. ən ə feɪd. ən sʌmθɪŋ wɝs.

Ingtar kept the others back, and dismounted to walk through the campsite with Uno, examining the ground. Hurin rode the circumference of the site, sniffing. Rand sat his stallion with the other men; he had no desire for any closer look at a place where Trollocs and Darkfriends had camped. And a Fade. And something worse.

mæt skɹæmbəld ʌp ðə hɪl əfʊɾ ən stɔkt ɪndə ðə kæmpsaɪt. "ɪz ðɪs wʌɾ ə dɑɹkfɹɛn kæmp lʊks laɪk? smɛlz ə bɪt, bʌɾ aɪ kæn seɪ ɪt lʊks ɛni dɪfɹən fɹəm ɛnibəɾi ɛlsəz." hi kɪkt ət wʌn ə ði æʃ hips, nɑkɪŋ aʊɾ ə pis ə bɝn boʊn, ən stup tə pɪk ɪɾ ʌp. "wʌt də dɑɹkfɹɛnz it? dʌzn lʊk laɪk ə ʃip boʊn, əɹ ə kaʊ."

Mat scrambled up the hill afoot and stalked into the campsite. "Is this what a Darkfriend camp looks like? Smells a bit, but I can't say it looks any different from anybody else's." He kicked at one of the ash heaps, knocking out a piece of burned bone, and stooped to pick it up. "What do Darkfriends eat? Doesn't look like a sheep bone, or a cow."

"ðɛɹ wɑz mɝɾɝ dʌn hɪɹ," hʊɹɪn sɛd mɔɹnfəli. hi skɹʌbd əɾ ɪz noʊz wɪð ə kɝtʃəf. "wɝs ðən mɝɾɝ."

"There was murder done here," Hurin said mournfully. He scrubbed at his nose with a kerchief. "Worse than murder."

"ðɛɹ wɝ tʃɹɑləks hɪɹ," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd, lʊkɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ ət mæt. "aɪ səpoʊz ðeɪ ɡɑt hʌŋɡɹi, ən ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz wɝ hændi." mæt dʒɹɑp ðə blækən boʊn; hi lʊkt əz ɪf i wɝ gɑnə bi sɪk.

"There were Trollocs here," Ingtar said, looking straight at Mat. "I suppose they got hungry, and the Darkfriends were handy." Mat dropped the blackened bone; he looked as if he were going to be sick.

"ðeɪ ɑɹ nɑt ɡoʊɪŋ saʊθ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ, maɪ lɔɹd," hʊɹɪn sɛd. ðət tʊk ɛvɹiwʌnz ətɛnʃən. hi pɔɪntəd bæk, tə ðə nɔɹθist. "meɪbi ðeɪv dɪsaɪɾɪd tə bɹeɪk fəɹ ðə blaɪɾ æftɝ ɔl. ɡoʊ ɝaʊn ʌs. meɪbi ðeɪ wɝ dʒʌs tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʊɾ əs ɔf baɪ kʌmɪŋ saʊθ." hi dɪd nɑt saʊn əz ɪf i bɪlivd ɪt. hi saʊndəd pʌzəld.

"They are not going south any longer, my Lord," Hurin said. That took everyone's attention. He pointed back, to the northeast. "Maybe they've decided to break for the Blight after all. Go around us. Maybe they were just trying to put us off by coming south." He did not sound as if he believed it. He sounded puzzled.

"wʌtɛvɝ ðeɪ wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ," ɪŋtʃɹ snɑɹəld, "aɪl əv əm naʊ. maʊnt!"

"Whatever they were trying," Ingtar snarled, "I'll have them now. Mount!"

lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən ən aʊɝ leɪɾɝ, ðoʊ, hʊɹɪn dʒɹu ɹeɪn. "ðeɪ tʃeɪnʒd əɡɛn, maɪ lɔɹd. saʊθ əɡɛn. ən ðeɪ kɪl sʌmwʌn ɛls hɪɹ."

Little more than an hour later, though, Hurin drew rein. "They changed again, my Lord. South again. And they killed someone else here."

ðəɹ wɝ noʊ æʃəz ðɛɹ, ɪn ðə ɡæp bɪtwin tu hɪlz, bʌɾ ə fju mɪnəts' sɝtʃ faʊn ðə bɑɾi. ə mæn kɝld ʌp ən stʌft ʌndɝ səm bʊʃəz. ðə bæk ə hɪz hɛd wɑz smæʃt ɪn, ən ɪz aɪz stɪl bʌlʒd wɪð ðə fɔɹs ə ðə bloʊ. noʊ wʌn ɹɛkəɡnaɪz hɪm, ðoʊ hi wɑz wɛɹɪŋ ʃaɪnɝən kloʊðz.

There were no ashes there, in the gap between two hills, but a few minutes' search found the body. A man curled up and stuffed under some bushes. The back of his head was smashed in, and his eyes still bulged with the force of the blow. No one recognized him, though he was wearing Shienaran clothes.

"wil weɪs noʊ taɪm bɛɹiɪŋ dɑɹkfɹɛnz," ɪŋtʃɹ ɡɹaʊld. "wi ɹaɪd saʊθ." hi suɾəd ɪz oʊn wɝdz ɔlmoʊs bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ wɝ aʊɾ ə hɪz maʊθ.

"We'll waste no time burying Darkfriends," Ingtar growled. "We ride south." He suited his own words almost before they were out of his mouth.

ðə deɪ wɑz ðə seɪm əz ðə deɪ bɪfɔɹ hæd bɪn, ðoʊ. ənoʊ stʌɾid tʃɹæks ən dʒɹɑpɪŋz, ən sɛd ðeɪ hæd ɡeɪn ə lɪɾəl ɡɹaʊn ɑn ðɛɹ kwɔɹi. twaɪlaɪt keɪm wɪð noʊ saɪɾ ə tʃɹɑləks əɹ dɑɹkfɹɛnz, ən ðə nɛks mɔɹnɪŋ ðəɹ wɑz ənʌðɝ əbændən kæmp - ən ənʌðɝ mɝɾɝ dʌn, soʊ hʊɹɪn sɛd - ən ənʌðɝ tʃeɪnʒ ə dɝɛkʃən, ðɪs taɪm tə ðə nɔɹθwɛst. lɛs ðən tu aʊɝz ɑn ðət tʃɹæk faʊn ənʌðɝ bɑɾi, ə mæn wɪð ɪz skʌl splɪɾ oʊpən baɪ ən æks, ən ənʌðɝ tʃeɪnʒ ə dɝɛkʃən. saʊθ əɡɛn. əɡɛn ɡeɪnɪŋ ɡɹaʊnd, baɪ ənoʊz ɹɛɾɪŋ ə ðə tʃɹæks. əɡɛn siɪŋ nʌθɪŋ bʌt dɪstən fɑɹmz əntɪl naɪtfɔl. ən ðə nɛks deɪ wɑz ðə seɪm, tʃeɪnʒəz ɪn dɝɛkʃən, mɝɾɝz ən ɔl. ən ðə nɛkst.

The day was the same as the day before had been, though. Uno studied tracks and droppings, and said they had gained a little ground on their quarry. Twilight came with no sight of Trollocs or Darkfriends, and the next morning there was another abandoned camp - and another murder done, so Hurin said - and another change of direction, this time to the northwest. Less than two hours on that track found another body, a man with his skull split open by an axe, and another change of direction. South again. Again gaining ground, by Uno's reading of the tracks. Again seeing nothing but distant farms until nightfall. And the next day was the same, changes in direction, murders and all. And the next.

ɛvɹi deɪ bɹɔɾ əm ə lɪɾəl kloʊsɝ bɪhaɪn ðɛɹ pɹeɪ, bʌɾ ɪŋtʃɹ fjumd. hi sədʒɛstəd kʌɾɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ əkɹɔs wən ðə tʃɹeɪl tʃeɪnʒd dɝɛkʃən ʌv ə mɔɹnɪŋ - ʃʊɹli ðeɪ wəd kʌm ɑn ðə tʃɹeɪl hɛɾɪŋ saʊθ əɡɛn, ən ɡeɪn mɔɹ taɪm - ən bɪfɔɹ ɛniwʌn kəd spik, hi sɛɾ ɪt wɑz ə bæɾ aɪdiə, ɪn keɪs ðɪs wʌns ðə mɛn ðeɪ hʌntəd dɪd nɑt tɝn saʊθ. hi ɝdʒd ɛvɹiwʌn tə ɡɹeɪɾɝ spid, tə stɑɹɾ ɝliɝ ən ɹaɪd tɪl fʊl dɑɹk. hi ɹimaɪndəɾ əm ə ðə tʃɑɹdʒ ði æmɪɝlɪn sit hæd ɡɪvən ðɛm, tə ɹɪkʌvɝ ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ, ən lɛt nʌθɪŋ bɑɹ ðɛɹ weɪ. hi spoʊk ə ðə ɡlɔɹi ðeɪ wəd hæv, ðɛɹ neɪmz ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ɪn stɔɹi ən hɪstɝi, ɪn ɡlimənz teɪlz ən bɑɹdz' sɔŋz, ðə mɛn u faʊn ðə hɔɹn. hi tɔkt əz ɪf i kəd nɑt stɑp, ən i stɛɹd daʊn ðə tʃɹeɪl ðeɪ fɑloʊɾ əz ɪf ɪz hoʊp ə ðə laɪt leɪ ət ði ɛn ʌv ɪt. ivən ənoʊ bɪɡæn tə lʊk əɾ ɪm əskæns.

Every day brought them a little closer behind their prey, but Ingtar fumed. He suggested cutting straight across when the trail changed direction of a morning - surely they would come on the trail heading south again, and gain more time - and before anyone could speak, he said it was a bad idea, in case this once the men they hunted did not turn south. He urged everyone to greater speed, to start earlier and ride till full dark. He reminded them of the charge the Amyrlin Seat had given them, to recover the Horn of Valere, and let nothing bar their way. He spoke of the glory they would have, their names remembered in story and history, in gleemen's tales and bards' songs, the men who found the Horn. He talked as if he could not stop, and he stared down the trail they followed as if his hope of the Light lay at the end of it. Even Uno began to look at him askance.

ən soʊ ðeɪ keɪm tə ðə ɹɪvɝ ɛɹɪnɪn.

And so they came to the River Erinin.

ɪt kəd nɑt pɹɑpɝli bi kɔld ə vɪlədʒ əɾ ɔl, tə ɹændz maɪnd. hi sæɾ ɪz hɔɹs əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz, piɹɪŋ ʌp ət hæf ə dʌzən smɔl haʊsəz wɪð wʊd-ʃɪŋɡəld ɹufs ən ivz ɔlmoʊs tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ɑn ə hɪltɑp oʊvɝlʊkɪŋ ðə ɹɪvɝ bɪniθ ðə mɔɹnɪŋ sʌn. fju pipəl pæs ðɪs weɪ. ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə fju aʊɝz sɪns ðeɪ hæd bɹoʊkən kæmp, bʌt pæs taɪm fəɹ əm tə hæv faʊn ðə ɹɪmeɪnz ə ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz' ɹɛstɪŋ pleɪs ɪf ðə pæɾɝn hɛld. ðeɪ hæd sin nʌθɪŋ ə ðə sɔɹt, haʊɛvɝ.

It could not properly be called a village at all, to Rand's mind. He sat his horse among the trees, peering up at half a dozen small houses with wood-shingled roofs and eaves almost to the ground, on a hilltop overlooking the river beneath the morning sun. Few people passed this way. It was only a few hours since they had broken camp, but past time for them to have found the remains of the Darkfriends' resting place if the pattern held. They had seen nothing of the sort, however.

ðə ɹɪvɝ ɪtsɛlf wɑz nɑt mʌtʃ laɪk ðə maɪɾi ɛɹɪnɪn ə stɔɹi, hɪɹ soʊ fɑɹ təwɔɹɾ ɪts sɔɹs ɪn ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝld. pɝhæps sɪksti peɪsɪz ə swɪft wɔɾɝ tə ðə fɑɹ bæŋk, laɪnd wɪð tʃɹiz, ən ə bɑɹdʒ-laɪk fɛɹi ɑn ə θɪk ɹoʊp spænɪŋ ðə dɪstəns. ðə fɛɹi sæt snʌɡd əɡɛns ði ʌðɝ saɪd.

The river itself was not much like the mighty Erinin of story, here so far toward its source in the Spine of the World. Perhaps sixty paces of swift water to the far bank, lined with trees, and a barge-like ferry on a thick rope spanning the distance. The ferry sat snugged against the other side.

fəɹ wʌns ðə tʃɹeɪl hæd lɛd stʃɹeɪt tə hjumən hæbəteɪʃən. stʃɹeɪt tə ðə haʊsəz ɑn ðə hɪl. noʊ wʌn muvd ɑn ðə sɪŋɡəl dɝt stʃɹiɾ ɝaʊnd wɪtʃ ðə dwɛlɪŋz klʌstɝd.

For once the trail had led straight to human habitation. Straight to the houses on the hill. No one moved on the single dirt street around which the dwellings clustered.

"æmbʊʃ, maɪ lɔɹd?" ənoʊ sɛd sɔfli.

"Ambush, my Lord?" Uno said softly.

ɪŋtʃɹ ɡeɪv ðə nɛsəsɛɹi ɔɹɾɝz, ən ðə ʃaɪnɝənz ənlɪmbɝd ðɛɹ lænsɪz, swipɪŋ ɝaʊn tə ɛnsɝkəl ðə haʊsəz. əɾ ə hæn sɪɡnəl fɹəm ɪŋtʃɹ ðeɪ ɡæləp bɪtwin ðə haʊsəz fɹəm fɔɹ dɝɛkʃənz, θʌndɝɪŋ ɪn wɪð aɪz sɝtʃɪŋ, lænsɪz ɹɛɾi, dʌst ɹaɪzɪŋ ʌndɝ ðɛɹ hʊvz. nʌθɪŋ muv bʌt ðɛm. ðeɪ dʒɹu ɹeɪn, ən ðə dʌs bɪɡæn tə sɛɾəl.

Ingtar gave the necessary orders, and the Shienarans unlimbered their lances, sweeping around to encircle the houses. At a hand signal from Ingtar they galloped between the houses from four directions, thundering in with eyes searching, lances ready, dust rising under their hooves. Nothing moved but them. They drew rein, and the dust began to settle.

ɹænd ɹɪtɝn tə hɪz kwɪvɝ ði æɹoʊ hi hæd nɑkt, ən slʌŋ ɪz baʊ ɑn ɪz bæk əɡɛn. mæt ən pɛɹɪn dɪd ðə seɪm. lɔɪəl ən hʊɹɪn hæd dʒʌst weɪɾəd ðəɹ wɛɹ ɪŋtʃɹ hæd lɛf ðɛm, wɑtʃɪŋ ənizəli.

Rand returned to his quiver the arrow he had nocked, and slung his bow on his back again. Mat and Perrin did the same. Loial and Hurin had just waited there where Ingtar had left them, watching uneasily.

ɪŋtʃɹ weɪvd, ən ɹænd ən ði ʌðɝz ɹoʊɾ ʌp tə dʒɔɪn ðə ʃaɪnɝənz.

Ingtar waved, and Rand and the others rode up to join the Shienarans.

"aɪ doʊn laɪk ðə smɛl ə ðɪs pleɪs," pɛɹɪn mʌɾɝd əz ðeɪ keɪm əmʌŋ ðə haʊsəz. hʊɹɪn ɡeɪv ɪm ə lʊk, ən i stɛɹd bæk əntɪl hʊɹɪn dʒɹɑpt ɪz aɪz. "ɪt smɛlz ɹɔŋ."

"I don't like the smell of this place," Perrin muttered as they came among the houses. Hurin gave him a look, and he stared back until Hurin dropped his eyes. "It smells wrong."

"blʌɾi dɑɹkfɹɛnz ən tʃɹɑləks wɛn stʃɹeɪt θɹu, maɪ lɔɹd," ənoʊ sɛd, pɔɪntɪŋ tə ə fju tʃɹæks nɑt tʃɑp tə pisəz baɪ ðə ʃaɪnɝənz. "stʃɹeɪt θɹu tə ðə ɡoʊt-kɪsɪŋ fɛɹi, wɪtʃ ðeɪ blʌɾi lɛft ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd. blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz! wɝ fleɪmɪŋ lʌki ðeɪ dɪdn kʌɾ ɪɾ ədʒɹɪft."

"Bloody Darkfriends and Trollocs went straight through, my Lord," Uno said, pointing to a few tracks not chopped to pieces by the Shienarans. "Straight through to the goat-kissing ferry, which they bloody left on the other side. Blood and bloody ashes! We're flaming lucky they didn't cut it adrift."

"wɛɹ ɑɹ ðə pipəl?" lɔɪəl æskt.

"Where are the people?" Loial asked.

dɔɹz stʊɾ oʊpən, kɝɾənz flæpt əɾ oʊpən wɪndoʊz, bʌt noʊ wʌn hæd kʌm aʊt fəɹ ɔl ðə θʌndɝ ə hʊvz.

Doors stood open, curtains flapped at open windows, but no one had come out for all the thunder of hooves.

"sɝtʃ ðə haʊsəz," ɪŋtʃɹ kəmændəd. mɛn dɪsmaʊntɪɾ ən ɹæn tə kəmplaɪ, bʌt ðeɪ keɪm bæk ʃeɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ hɛdz.

"Search the houses," Ingtar commanded. Men dismounted and ran to comply, but they came back shaking their heads.

"ðeɪɹ dʒʌst ɡɔn, maɪ lɔɹd," ənoʊ sɛd. "dʒʌs blʌɾi ɡɔn, bɝn mi. laɪk ðeɪd pɪkt ʌp ən dɪsaɪɾɪd tə fleɪmɪŋ wɔk əweɪ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə blʌɾi deɪ." hi stɑp sʌɾənli, pɔɪntɪŋ ɝdʒənli tə ə haʊs bɪhaɪn ɪŋtʃɹ. "ðɛɹz ə wʊmən ət ðət wɪndoʊ. haʊ aɪ blʌɾi mɪs hɝ. . . ." hi wɑz ɹʌnɪŋ fəɹ ðə haʊs bɪfɔɹ ɛniwʌn ɛls kəd muv.

"They're just gone, my Lord," Uno said. "Just bloody gone, burn me. Like they'd picked up and decided to flaming walk away in the middle of the bloody day." He stopped suddenly, pointing urgently to a house behind Ingtar. "There's a woman at that window. How I bloody missed her. . . ." He was running for the house before anyone else could move.

"doʊn fɹaɪɾən hɝ!" ɪŋtʃɹ ʃaʊɾəd. "ənoʊ, wi niɾ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən. ðə laɪt blaɪn ju, ənoʊ, doʊn fɹaɪɾən hɝ!" ðə wʌn-aɪd mæn dɪsəpɪɹd θɹu ði oʊpən dɔɹ. ɪŋtʃɹ ɹeɪzd ɪz vɔɪs əɡɛn. "wi wɪl nɑt hɑɹm ju, ɡʊd leɪɾi. wəɹ lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝz oʊθmɛn, fɹəm fæl dæɹə. də nɑt bi əfɹeɪd! wɪl nɑt hɑɹm ju."

"Don't frighten her!" Ingtar shouted. "Uno, we need information. The Light blind you, Uno, don't frighten her!" The one-eyed man disappeared through the open door. Ingtar raised his voice again. "We will not harm you, good lady. We are Lord Agelmar's oathmen, from Fal Dara. Do not be afraid! We will not harm you."

ə wɪndoʊ ət ðə tɑp ə ðə haʊs flu ʌp, ən ənoʊ stʌk ɪz hɛɾ aʊt, stɛɹɪŋ ɝaʊnd waɪldli. wɪð ən oʊθ i pʊl bæk. θʌmps ən klæɾɝz mɑɹkt ɪz pæsədʒ bæk, əz ɪf i wɝ kɪkɪŋ θɪŋz ɪn fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən. faɪnəli hi əpɪɹd fɹəm ðə dɔɹweɪ.

A window at the top of the house flew up, and Uno stuck his head out, staring around wildly. With an oath he pulled back. Thumps and clatters marked his passage back, as if he were kicking things in frustration. Finally he appeared from the doorway.

"ɡɔn, maɪ lɔɹd. bʌt ʃi wɑz ðɛɹ. ə wʊmən ɪn ə waɪt dʒɹɛs, ət ðə wɪndoʊ. aɪ sɔ hɝ. aɪ ivən θɔɾ aɪ sɔ hɝ ɪnsaɪd, fəɹ ə moʊmənt, bʌt ðən ʃi wɑz ɡɔn, ænd. . . ." hi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. "ðə haʊs ɪz ɛmpti, maɪ lɔɹd." ɪt wɑz ə mɛʒɝ ə hɪz ædʒəteɪʃən ðəɾ i dɪd nɑt kɝs.

"Gone, my Lord. But she was there. A woman in a white dress, at the window. I saw her. I even thought I saw her inside, for a moment, but then she was gone, and. . . ." He took a deep breath. "The house is empty, my Lord." It was a measure of his agitation that he did not curse.

"kɝɾənz," mæt mʌɾɝd. "hiz dʒʌmpɪŋ ət blʌɾi kɝɾənz." ənoʊ ɡeɪv ɪm ə ʃɑɹp lʊk, ðən ɹɪtɝn tə hɪz hɔɹs.

"Curtains," Mat muttered. "He's jumping at bloody curtains." Uno gave him a sharp look, then returned to his horse.

"wɛɹ dɪd ðeɪ ɡoʊ?" ɹænd æsk lɔɪəl. "du jə θɪŋk ðeɪ ɹæn ɔf wən ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz keɪm?" ən tʃɹɑləks, ən ə mɹdʒɹɑl. ən hʊɹɪnz sʌmθɪŋ wɝs. smɑɹt pipəl, ɪf ðeɪ ɹæn əz hɑɹɾ əz ðeɪ kʊd.

"Where did they go?" Rand asked Loial. "Do you think they ran off when the Darkfriends came?" And Trollocs, and a Myrddraal. And Hurin's something worse. Smart people, if they ran as hard as they could.

"aɪ fɪɹ ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz tʊk ðɛm, ɹænd," lɔɪəl sɛd sloʊli. hi ɡɹɪməst, ɔlmoʊst ə snɑɹl wɪð ɪz bɹɔd noʊz laɪk ə snaʊt. "fɔɹ ðə tʃɹɑləks." ɹænd swɑloʊɾ ən wɪʃt i hæd nɑɾ æskt; ɪt wɑz nɛvɝ plɛzən tə θɪŋk ɑn haʊ tʃɹɑləks fɛd.

"I fear the Darkfriends took them, Rand," Loial said slowly. He grimaced, almost a snarl with his broad nose like a snout. "For the Trollocs." Rand swallowed and wished he had not asked; it was never pleasant to think on how Trollocs fed.

"wʌtɛvɝ wɑz dʌn hɪɹ," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd, "aʊɝ dɑɹkfɹɛnz dɪɾ ɪt. hʊɹɪn, wɑz ðəɹ vaɪələns hɪɹ? kɪlɪŋ? hʊɹɪn!"

"Whatever was done here," Ingtar said, "our Darkfriends did it. Hurin, was there violence here? Killing? Hurin!"

ðə snɪfɝ ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ ɪn ɪz sæɾəl ən lʊkt ɝaʊnd waɪldli. hi hæd bɪn stɛɹɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə ɹɪvɝ. "vaɪələns, maɪ lɔɹd? jɛs. kɪlɪŋ, noʊ. əɹ nɑɾ ɪɡzækli." hi ɡlænst saɪdweɪz ət pɛɹɪn. "aɪv nɛvɝ smɛld ɛniθɪŋ ɪɡzækli laɪk ɪt bɪfɔɹ, maɪ lɔɹd. bʌt ðəɹ wɑz hɝɾɪŋ dʌn."

The sniffer gave a start in his saddle and looked around wildly. He had been staring across the river. "Violence, my Lord? Yes. Killing, no. Or not exactly." He glanced sideways at Perrin. "I've never smelled anything exactly like it before, my Lord. But there was hurting done."

"ɪz ðəɹ ɛni daʊt ðeɪ kɹɔst oʊvɝ? hæv ðeɪ dʌbəl bæk əɡɛn?"

"Is there any doubt they crossed over? Have they doubled back again?"

"ðeɪ kɹɔst, maɪ lɔɹd." hʊɹɪn lʊkt ənizəli ət ðə fɑɹ bæŋk. "ðeɪ kɹɔst. wʌt ðeɪ dɪɾ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd, ðoʊ. . . ." hi ʃɹʌɡd.

"They crossed, my Lord." Hurin looked uneasily at the far bank. "They crossed. What they did on the other side, though. . . ." He shrugged.

ɪŋtʃɹ nɑɾəd. "ənoʊ, aɪ wɑn ðət fɛɹi bæk ɑn ðɪs saɪd. ən aɪ wɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd skaʊɾəd bɪfɔɹ wi kɹɔs. dʒʌs kəz ðəɹ wɑz noʊ æmbʊʃ hɪɹ dʌzn min ðəɹ wɪl nɑt bi wʌn wən wəɹ splɪt baɪ ðə ɹɪvɝ. ðət fɛɹi dʌz nɑt lʊk bɪɡ ɪnʌf tə kæɹi əs ɔl ɪn wʌn tʃɹɪp. si tə ɪt."

Ingtar nodded. "Uno, I want that ferry back on this side. And I want the other side scouted before we cross. Just because there was no ambush here doesn't mean there will not be one when we are split by the river. That ferry does not look big enough to carry us all in one trip. See to it."

ənoʊ baʊd, ən ɪn moʊməns ɹeɪɡən ən mæsimə wɝ hɛlpɪŋ itʃ ʌðɝ aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ ɑɹmɝ. stʃɹɪp daʊn tə bɹitʃklaʊts, wɪð ə dæɡɝ stʌk bɪhaɪn ɪn ðə smɔl ə ðə bæk, ðeɪ tʃɹɑɾəd tə ðə ɹɪvɝ ɑn hɔɹsmənz baʊd lɛɡz ən weɪɾɪd ɪn, bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə wɝk ðɛɹ weɪ hæn oʊvɝ hæn əlɔŋ ðə θɪk ɹoʊp əlɔŋ wɪtʃ ðə fɛɹi ɹæn. ðə keɪbəl sæɡd ɪnʌf ɪn ðə mɪɾəl tə pʊɾ əm ɪn ðə ɹɪvɝ tə ðɛɹ weɪsts, ən ðə kɝənt wɑz stʃɹɔŋ, pʊlɪŋ əm daʊnstʃɹim, jɛɾ ɪn lɛs taɪm ðən ɹænd ɪkspɛktəd ðeɪ wɝ hɔlɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz oʊvɝ ðə slæɾɪd saɪdz ə ðə fɛɹi. dʒɹɔɪŋ ðɛɹ dæɡɝz, ðeɪ dɪsəpɪɹɾ ɪndə ðə tʃɹiz.

Uno bowed, and in moments Ragan and Masema were helping each other out of their armor. Stripped down to breechclouts, with a dagger stuck behind in the small of the back, they trotted to the river on horsemen's bowed legs and waded in, beginning to work their way hand over hand along the thick rope along which the ferry ran. The cable sagged enough in the middle to put them in the river to their waists, and the current was strong, pulling them downstream, yet in less time than Rand expected they were hauling themselves over the slatted sides of the ferry. Drawing their daggers, they disappeared into the trees.

æftɝ wʌt sim laɪk fɝɛvɝ, ðə tu mɛn ɹiəpɪɹɾ ən bɪɡæn pʊlɪŋ ðə fɛɹi sloʊli əkɹɔs. ðə bɑɹdʒ bʌɾɪd əɡɛns ðə bæŋk bɪloʊ ðə vɪlədʒ, ən mæsimə taɪɾ ɪɾ ɔf waɪl ɹeɪɡən tʃɹɑɾəd ʌp tə wɛɹ ɪŋtʃɹ weɪɾəd. hɪz feɪs wɑz peɪl, ði æɹoʊ skɑɹ ɑn ɪz tʃik ʃɑɹp, ən i saʊndəd ʃeɪkən.

After what seemed like forever, the two men reappeared and began pulling the ferry slowly across. The barge butted against the bank below the village, and Masema tied it off while Ragan trotted up to where Ingtar waited. His face was pale, the arrow scar on his cheek sharp, and he sounded shaken.

"ðə fɑɹ bæŋk. . . . ðəɹ ɪz noʊ æmbʊʃ ɑn ðə fɑɹ bæŋk, maɪ lɔɹd, bʌt. . . ." hi baʊd dipli, stɪl wɛɾ ən ʃɪvɝɪŋ fɹəm ɪz ɪkskɝʒən. "maɪ lɔɹd, jə mʌst si fəɹ jɝsɛlf. ðə bɪɡ stoʊnioʊk, fɪfti peɪsɪz saʊθ fɹəm ðə lændɪŋ. aɪ kænɑt seɪ ðə wɝdz. jə mʌst si ɪt jɝsɛlf."

"The far bank. . . . There is no ambush on the far bank, my Lord, but. . . ." He bowed deeply, still wet and shivering from his excursion. "My Lord, you must see for yourself. The big stoneoak, fifty paces south from the landing. I cannot say the words. You must see it yourself."

ɪŋtʃɹ fɹaʊnd, lʊkɪŋ fɹəm ɹeɪɡən tə ði ʌðɝ bæŋk. faɪnəli, hi sɛd, "ju hæv dʌn wɛl, ɹeɪɡən. boʊθ ə jə hæv." hɪz vɔɪs bɪkeɪm mɔɹ bɹɪsk. "faɪn ðiz mɛn sʌmθɪŋ tə dʒɹaɪ ðɛmsɛlvz ɑn fɹəm ðə haʊsəz, ənoʊ. ən si ɪf ɛnibəɾi lɛft wɔɾɝ ɑn fəɹ ti. pʊt sʌmθɪŋ hɑɾ ɪndə ðɛm, ɪf jə kæn. ðən bɹɪŋ ðə sɛkən faɪl ən ðə pæk ænəməlz oʊvɝ." hi tɝn tə ɹænd. "wɛl, ɑɹ jə ɹɛɾi tə si ðə saʊθ bæŋk ə ði ɛɹɪnɪn?" hi dɪd nɑt weɪt fəɹ ən ænsɝ, bʌt ɹoʊd daʊn tə ðə fɛɹi wɪð hʊɹɪn ən hæf ðə lænsɝz.

Ingtar frowned, looking from Ragan to the other bank. Finally, he said, "You have done well, Ragan. Both of you have." His voice became more brisk. "Find these men something to dry themselves on from the houses, Uno. And see if anybody left water on for tea. Put something hot into them, if you can. Then bring the second file and the pack animals over." He turned to Rand. "Well, are you ready to see the south bank of the Erinin?" He did not wait for an answer, but rode down to the ferry with Hurin and half the lancers.

ɹænd hɛzɪteɪɾɪd oʊnli ə moʊmən bɪfɔɹ fɑloʊɪŋ. lɔɪəl wɛnt wɪð hɪm. tə hɪz sɝpɹaɪz, pɛɹɪn ɹoʊd daʊn əhɛɾ ə ðɛm, lʊkɪŋ ɡɹɪm. səm ə ðə lænsɝz, meɪkɪŋ ɡɹʌf dʒoʊks, dɪsmaʊntɪd tə hɔl ɑn ðə ɹoʊp ən wɔk ðə fɛɹi oʊvɝ.

Rand hesitated only a moment before following. Loial went with him. To his surprise, Perrin rode down ahead of them, looking grim. Some of the lancers, making gruff jokes, dismounted to haul on the rope and walk the ferry over.

mæt weɪɾəd əntɪl ðə læs mɪnət, wən wʌn ə ðə ʃaɪnɝənz wɑz əntiɪŋ ðə fɛɹi, bɪfɔɹ i kɪkt ɪz hɔɹs ən kɹaʊɾəd əbɔɹd. "aɪ hæv tə kʌm sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ, doʊn aɪ?" hi sɛd, bɹɛθləs, tə noʊ wʌn ɪn pɝtɪkjəlɝ. "aɪ hæv tə faɪn ɪt."

Mat waited until the last minute, when one of the Shienarans was untying the ferry, before he kicked his horse and crowded aboard. "I have to come sooner or later, don't I?" he said, breathless, to no one in particular. "I have to find it."

ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. wɪð mæt lʊkɪŋ əz hɛlθi əz i ɛvɝ hæd, hi hæɾ ɔlmoʊs fɝɡɑɾən waɪ hi wɑz əlɔŋ. tə faɪn ðə dæɡɝ. lɛɾ ɪŋtʃɹ əv ðə hɔɹn. aɪ dʒʌst wɑn ðə dæɡɝ fəɹ mæt. "wi wɪl faɪn ɪt, mæt."

Rand shook his head. With Mat looking as healthy as he ever had, he had almost forgotten why he was along. To find the dagger. Let Ingtar have the Horn. I just want the dagger for Mat. "We will find it, Mat."

mæt skaʊld əɾ ɪm - wɪð ə snɪɹɪŋ ɡlæns fəɹ ɪz faɪn ɹɛd koʊt - ən tɝn əweɪ. ɹænd saɪd.

Mat scowled at him - with a sneering glance for his fine red coat - and turned away. Rand sighed.

"ɪt wɪl ɔl kʌm ɹaɪt, ɹænd," lɔɪəl sɛd kwaɪətli. "sʌmhaʊ, ɪt wɪl."

"It will all come right, Rand," Loial said quietly. "Somehow, it will."

ðə kɝən tʊk ðə fɛɹi əz ɪt wɑz hɔld aʊt fɹəm ðə bæŋk, tʌɡɪŋ ɪɾ əɡɛns ðə keɪbəl wɪð ə ʃɑɹp kɹik. ðə lænsɝz wɝ ɑd fɛɹimən, wɔkɪŋ ðə dɛk ɪn hɛlməts ən ɑɹmɝ, wɪð sɔɹdz ɑn ðɛɹ bæks, bʌt ðeɪ tʊk ðə fɛɹi aʊɾ ɪndə ðə ɹɪvɝ wɛl ɪnʌf.

The current took the ferry as it was hauled out from the bank, tugging it against the cable with a sharp creak. The lancers were odd ferrymen, walking the deck in helmets and armor, with swords on their backs, but they took the ferry out into the river well enough.

"ðɪs ɪz haʊ wi lɛf hoʊm," pɛɹɪn sɛd sʌɾənli. "æt tɛɹən fɛɹi. ðə fɛɹimənz buts klʌŋkɪŋ ɑn ðə dɛk, ən ðə wɔɾɝ ɡɝɡəlɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə fɛɹi. ðɪs ɪz haʊ wi lɛft. ɪɾəl bi wɝs, ðɪs taɪm."

"This is how we left home," Perrin said suddenly. "At Taren Ferry. The ferrymen's boots clunking on the deck, and the water gurgling around the ferry. This is how we left. It will be worse, this time."

"haʊ kən ɪt bi wɝs?" ɹænd æskt. pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑɾ ænsɝ. hi sɝtʃt ðə fɑɹ bæŋk, ən ɪz ɡoʊldən aɪz ɔlmoʊst sim tə ʃaɪn, bʌt nɑt wɪð iɡɝnəs.

"How can it be worse?" Rand asked. Perrin did not answer. He searched the far bank, and his golden eyes almost seemed to shine, but not with eagerness.

æftɝ ə mɪnət, mæt æskt, "haʊ kən ɪt bi wɝs?"

After a minute, Mat asked, "How can it be worse?"

"ɪt wɪl bi. aɪ kən smɛl ɪt," wɑz ɔl pɛɹɪn wəd seɪ. hʊɹɪn aɪɾ ɪm nɝvəsli, bʌt ðən hʊɹɪn sim tə bi aɪɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ nɝvəsli sɪns ðeɪ hæd lɛft fæl dæɹə.

"It will be. I can smell it," was all Perrin would say. Hurin eyed him nervously, but then Hurin seemed to be eyeing everything nervously since they had left Fal Dara.

ðə fɛɹi bʌmpt əɡɛns ðə saʊθ bæŋk wɪð ə hɑloʊ θʌɾ ə staʊt plæŋks əɡɛns hɑɹd kleɪ, ɔlmoʊst ʌndɝ oʊvɝhæŋɪŋ tʃɹiz, ən ðə ʃaɪnɝənz u hæd bɪn hɔlɪŋ ɑn ðə ɹoʊp maʊntəd ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz, ɪksɛp fəɹ tu ɪŋtʃɹ toʊl tə teɪk ðə fɛɹi bæk oʊvɝ fəɹ ði ʌðɝz. ðə ɹɛs fɑloʊɾ ɪŋtʃɹ ʌp ðə bæŋk.

The ferry bumped against the south bank with a hollow thud of stout planks against hard clay, almost under overhanging trees, and the Shienarans who had been hauling on the rope mounted their horses, except for two Ingtar told to take the ferry back over for the others. The rest followed Ingtar up the bank.

"fɪfti peɪsɪz tə ə bɪɡ stoʊnioʊk," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛɾ əz ðeɪ ɹoʊɾ ɪndə ðə tʃɹiz. hi saʊndəd tu mæɾɝ-ʌv-fækt. ɪf ɹeɪɡən kəd nɑt spik ʌv ɪt. . . . səm ə ðə soʊlʒɝz iz ðə sɔɹdz ɑn ðɛɹ bæks, ən hɛl ðɛɹ lænsɪz ɹɛɾi.

"Fifty paces to a big stoneoak," Ingtar said as they rode into the trees. He sounded too matter-of-fact. If Ragan could not speak of it. . . . Some of the soldiers eased the swords on their backs, and held their lances ready.

ət fɝst ɹænd θɔt ðə fɪɡjɝz hæŋɪŋ baɪ ðɛɹ ɑɹmz fɹəm ðə θɪk ɡɹeɪ lɪmz ə ðə stoʊnioʊk wɝ skɑɹɛkɹoʊz. kɹɪmzən skɑɹɛkɹoʊz. ðən i ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə tu feɪsəz. tʃæŋɡʌ, ən ði ʌðɝ mæn u hæd bɪn ɑn ɡɑɹd wɪð hɪm. naɪdaʊ. aɪz stɛɹɪŋ, tiθ bɛɹɾ ɪn ə ɹɪktəs ə peɪn. ðeɪ hæd lɪvd ə lɔŋ taɪm æftɝ ɪt bɪɡæn.

At first Rand thought the figures hanging by their arms from the thick gray limbs of the stoneoak were scarecrows. Crimson scarecrows. Then he recognized the two faces. Changu, and the other man who had been on guard with him. Nidao. Eyes staring, teeth bared in a rictus of pain. They had lived a long time after it began.

pɛɹɪn meɪɾ ə saʊn ɪn ɪz θɹoʊt, nɪɹli ə ɡɹaʊl.

Perrin made a sound in his throat, nearly a growl.

"æz bæɾ əz ɛvɝ aɪv sin, maɪ lɔɹd," hʊɹɪn sɛd feɪnli. "æz bæɾ əz ɛvɝ aɪv smɛld, ɛksɛptɪŋ ðə dʌnʒən ət fæl dæɹə ðət naɪt."

"As bad as ever I've seen, my Lord," Hurin said faintly. "As bad as ever I've smelled, excepting the dungeon at Fal Dara that night."

fɹæntəkəli ɹænd sɔt ðə vɔɪd. ðə fleɪm sim tə ɡɛɾ ɪn ðə weɪ, ðə kwizi laɪt flʌɾɝɪŋ ɪn taɪm wɪð ɪz kənvʌlsɪv swɑloʊz, bʌɾ i pʊʃt ɑn əntɪl i hæd ɹæp hɪmsɛlf ɪn ɛmptinəs. ðə kwizinəs pʌlsd ɪn ðə vɔɪd wɪð hɪm, ðoʊ. nɑɾ aʊtsaɪd, fəɹ wʌns, bʌɾ ɪnsaɪd. noʊ wʌndɝ, lʊkɪŋ ət ðɪs. ðə θɔt skɪɾɝd əkɹɔs ðə vɔɪd laɪk ə dʒɹɑp ʌv wɔɾɝ ɑn ə hɑt ɡɹɪɾəl. wʌt hæpən tə ðɛm?

Frantically Rand sought the void. The flame seemed to get in the way, the queasy light fluttering in time with his convulsive swallows, but he pushed on until he had wrapped himself in emptiness. The queasiness pulsed in the void with him, though. Not outside, for once, but inside. No wonder, looking at this. The thought skittered across the void like a drop of water on a hot griddle. What happened to them?

"skɪn əlaɪv," hi hɝd sʌmwʌn bɪhaɪn ɪm seɪ, ən ðə saʊnz ə sʌmbɑɾi ɛls ɹɛtʃɪŋ. hi θɔɾ ɪt wɑz mæt, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɔl fɑɹ əweɪ fɹəm hɪm, ɪnsaɪd ðə vɔɪd. bʌt ðət nɔziəs flɪkɝɪŋ wɑz ɪn ðɛɹ, tu. hi θɔɾ i maɪt θɹoʊ ʌp hɪmsɛlf.

"Skinned alive," he heard someone behind him say, and the sounds of somebody else retching. He thought it was Mat, but it was all far away from him, inside the void. But that nauseous flickering was in there, too. He thought he might throw up himself.

"kʌɾ əm daʊn," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd hɑɹʃli. hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd ə moʊmənt, ðən æɾəd, "bɛɹi ðɛm. wi kænɑt bi ʃʊɹ ðeɪ wɝ dɑɹkfɹɛnz. ðeɪ cʊɾə bɪn teɪkən pɹɪznɝ. ðeɪ kəɾ əv bɪn. lɛɾ əm noʊ ðə læst ɛmbɹeɪs ə ðə mʌðɝ, ət list." mɛn ɹoʊd fɔɹwɝd dʒɪnʒɝli wɪð naɪvz; ivən fəɹ bæɾəl-hɑɹdənd ʃaɪnɝənz ɪt wɑz noʊ izi tæsk, kʌɾɪŋ daʊn ðə fleɪd kɔɹpsəz ə mɛn ðeɪ nu.

"Cut them down," Ingtar said harshly. He hesitated a moment, then added, "Bury them. We cannot be sure they were Darkfriends. They could have been taken prisoner. They could have been. Let them know the last embrace of the mother, at least." Men rode forward gingerly with knives; even for battle-hardened Shienarans it was no easy task, cutting down the flayed corpses of men they knew.

"ɑɹ jə ɔl ɹaɪt, ɹænd?" ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd. "aɪ æm nɑt juz tə ðɪs iðɝ."

"Are you all right, Rand?" Ingtar said. "I am not used to this either."

"aɪ . . . æm ɔl ɹaɪt, ɪŋtʃɹ." ɹænd lɛt ðə vɔɪd vænɪʃ. hi fɛlt lɛs sɪk wɪθaʊɾ ɪt; hɪz stʌmək stɪl kɝɾəld, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz bɛɾɝ. ɪŋtʃɹ nɑɾəd ən tɝn ɪz hɔɹs soʊ hi kəd wɑtʃ ðə mɛn wɝkɪŋ.

"I . . . am all right, Ingtar." Rand let the void vanish. He felt less sick without it; his stomach still curdled, but it was better. Ingtar nodded and turned his horse so he could watch the men working.

ðə bɛɹiəl wɑz sɪmpəl. tu hoʊlz dʌɡ ɪn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ən ðə bɑɾiz leɪɾ ɪn əz ðə ɹɛst ə ðə ʃaɪnɝənz wɑtʃt ɪn saɪləns. ðə ɡɹeɪv dɪɡɝz bɪɡæn ʃʌvlɪŋ ɝθ ɪndə ðə ɡɹeɪvz wɪð noʊ mɔɹ ədu.

The burial was simple. Two holes dug in the ground, and the bodies laid in as the rest of the Shienarans watched in silence. The grave diggers began shoveling earth into the graves with no more ado.

ɹænd wɑz ʃɑkt, bʌt lɔɪəl ɪkspleɪn sɔfli. "ʃaɪnɝənz bɪliv wi ɔl keɪm fɹəm ɝθ, ən mʌst ɹɪtɝn tə ɝθ. ðeɪ nɛvɝ juz kɔfɪnz əɹ ʃɹaʊdz, ən ðə bɑɾiz ɑɹ nɛvɝ kloʊðd. ði ɝθ mʌs hoʊl ðə bɑɾi. ðə læst ɛmbɹeɪs ə ðə mʌðɝ, ðeɪ kɔl ɪt. ən ðəɹ ɑɹ nɛvɝ ɛni wɝdz ɪksɛpt 'ðə laɪt ʃaɪn ɑn ju, ən ðə kɹieɪɾɝ ʃɛltɝ ju. ðə læst ɛmbɹeɪs ə ðə mʌðɝ wɛlkəm jə hoʊm.' " lɔɪəl saɪɾ ən ʃʊk ɪz hjudʒ hɛd. "aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk ɛniwʌn wɪl seɪ ðɛm ðɪs taɪm. noʊ mæɾɝ wʌɾ ɪŋtʃɹ sɛz, ɹænd, ðəɹ kænɑt bi mʌtʃ daʊt ðət tʃæŋɡʌ ən naɪdaʊ slu ðə ɡɑɹdz ət ðə dɔɡ ɡeɪɾ ən lɛt ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz ɪndə ðə kip. ɪt hæd tə bi ðeɪ hu wɝ ɹispɑnsəbəl fəɹ ɔl ʌv ɪt."

Rand was shocked, but Loial explained softly. "Shienarans believe we all came from earth, and must return to earth. They never use coffins or shrouds, and the bodies are never clothed. The earth must hold the body. The last embrace of the mother, they call it. And there are never any words except 'The Light shine on you, and the Creator shelter you. The last embrace of the mother welcome you home.' " Loial sighed and shook his huge head. "I do not think anyone will say them this time. No matter what Ingtar says, Rand, there cannot be much doubt that Changu and Nidao slew the guards at the Dog Gate and let the Darkfriends into the keep. It had to be they who were responsible for all of it."

"ðɛn u ʃɑt ði æɹoʊ ət - ət ði æmɪɝlɪn?" ɹænd swɑloʊd. hu ʃɑɾ ət mi? lɔɪəl sɛd nʌθɪŋ.

"Then who shot the arrow at - at the Amyrlin?" Rand swallowed. Who shot at me? Loial said nothing.

ənoʊ ɝaɪvd wɪð ðə ɹɛst ə ðə mɛn ən ðə pækhɔɹsɪz əz ðə læst ɝθ wɑz biɪŋ ʃʌvəld ɑntu ðə ɡɹeɪvz. sʌmwʌn toʊld ɪm wʌt ðeɪ hæd faʊnd, ən ðə wʌn-aɪd mæn spæt. "ɡoʊt-kɪsɪŋ tʃɹɑləks də ðəɾ əlɔŋ ðə blaɪt, səmtaɪmz. wən ðeɪ wɑnə ʃeɪk jəɹ blʌɾi nɝv, əɹ fleɪmɪŋ wɔɹn jə nɑt tə fɑloʊ. bɝn mi ɪf ɪt wɝks hɪɹ, iðɝ."

Uno arrived with the rest of the men and the packhorses as the last earth was being shoveled onto the graves. Someone told him what they had found, and the one-eyed man spat. "Goat-kissing Trollocs do that along the Blight, sometimes. When they want to shake your bloody nerve, or flaming warn you not to follow. Burn me if it works here, either."

bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ ɹoʊɾ əweɪ, ɪŋtʃɹ pɔzd ɑn ɪz hɔɹs bɪsaɪd ði ənmɑɹkt ɡɹeɪvz, tu maʊnz ə bɛɹ ɝθ ðət lʊk tu smɔl tə hoʊl mɛn. æftɝ ə moʊmən i sɛd, "ðə laɪt ʃaɪn ɑn ju, ən ðə kɹieɪɾɝ ʃɛltɝ ju. ðə læst ɛmbɹeɪs ə ðə mʌðɝ wɛlkəm jə hoʊm." wən i ɹeɪzd ɪz hɛd, hi lʊkt əɾ itʃ mæn ɪn tɝn. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɪkspɹɛʃən ɑn ɛni feɪs, list ʌv ɔl ɑn ɪŋtʃɹz. "ðeɪ seɪv lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ ət tɑɹwɪnz ɡæp," hi sɛd. sɛvɹəl ə ðə lænsɝz nɑɾəd. ɪŋtʃɹ tɝn ɪz hɔɹs. "wɪtʃ weɪ, hʊɹɪn?"

Before they rode away, Ingtar paused on his horse beside the unmarked graves, two mounds of bare earth that looked too small to hold men. After a moment he said, "The Light shine on you, and the Creator shelter you. The last embrace of the mother welcome you home." When he raised his head, he looked at each man in turn. There was no expression on any face, least of all on Ingtar's. "They saved Lord Agelmar at Tarwin's Gap," he said. Several of the lancers nodded. Ingtar turned his horse. "Which way, Hurin?"

"saʊθ, maɪ lɔɹd."

"South, my Lord."

"teɪk ðə tʃɹeɪl! wi hʌnt!"

"Take the trail! We hunt!"

ðə fɔɹəst sun ɡeɪv weɪ tə dʒɛnli ɹoʊlɪŋ flætlænd, səmtaɪmz kɹɔs baɪ ə ʃæloʊ stʃɹim ðət hæd dʌɡ ɪtsɛlf ə haɪ-bæŋk tʃænəl, wɪð nɛvɝ mɔɹ ðən ə loʊ ɹaɪz əɹ ə skwɑt hɪl ðət bɛɹli dɪzɝv ðə neɪm. pɝfəkt kʌntʃɹi fəɹ ðə hɔɹsəz. ɪŋtʃɹ tʊk ædvæntɪdʒ ʌv ɪt, sɛɾɪŋ ə stɛɾi, ɡɹaʊnd-kʌvɝɪŋ peɪs. əkeɪʒənəli ɹænd sɔ wʌt maɪɾ əv bɪn ə fɑɹmhaʊs ɪn ðə dɪstəns, ən wʌns wʌɾ i θɔt wɑz ə vɪlədʒ, wɪð smoʊk ɹaɪzɪŋ fɹəm tʃɪmniz ə fju maɪlz ɔf ən sʌmθɪŋ flæʃɪŋ waɪɾ ɪn ðə sʌn, bʌt ðə lænd nɪɹ əm steɪɾ ɛmpti ʌv hjumən laɪf, lɔŋ swɑðz ʌv ɡɹæs dɑɾəd wɪð bɹʌʃ ən əkeɪʒənəl tʃɹiz, wɪð naʊ ən əɡɛn ə smɔl θɪkɪt, nɛvɝ mɔɹ ðən ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz əkɹɔs.

The forest soon gave way to gently rolling flatland, sometimes crossed by a shallow stream that had dug itself a high-banked channel, with never more than a low rise or a squat hill that barely deserved the name. Perfect country for the horses. Ingtar took advantage of it, setting a steady, ground-covering pace. Occasionally Rand saw what might have been a farmhouse in the distance, and once what he thought was a village, with smoke rising from chimneys a few miles off and something flashing white in the sun, but the land near them stayed empty of human life, long swathes of grass dotted with brush and occasional trees, with now and again a small thicket, never more than a hundred paces across.

ɪŋtʃɹ pʊɾ aʊt skaʊts, tu mɛn ɹaɪɾɪŋ əhɛd, ɪn saɪɾ oʊnli wən ðeɪ tɑpt ən əkeɪʒənəl ɹaɪz. hi hæɾ ə sɪlvɝ wɪsəl hæŋɪŋ ɝaʊn ɪz nɛk tə kɔl əm bæk ɪf hʊɹɪn sɛd ðə tʃɹeɪl hæd vɪɹd, bʌɾ ɪt dɪd nɑt. saʊθ. ɔlweɪz saʊθ.

Ingtar put out scouts, two men riding ahead, in sight only when they topped an occasional rise. He had a silver whistle hanging around his neck to call them back if Hurin said the trail had veered, but it did not. South. Always south.

"wi wɪl ɹitʃ ðə fild ə tɑlədɑɹ ɪn θɹi əɹ fɔɹ deɪz ət ðɪs ɹeɪt," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛɾ əz ðeɪ ɹoʊd. "ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz ɡɹeɪɾəst sɪŋɡəl vɪktɝi, wən ðə hæfmən lɛd ðə tʃɹɑləks aʊɾ ə ðə blaɪɾ əɡɛns hɪm. sɪks deɪz ən naɪts, ɪt læstəd, ən wən ɪt wɑz dʌn, ðə tʃɹɑləks flɛd bæk ɪndə ðə blaɪɾ ən nɛvɝ dɛɹd tʃælənʒ ɪm əɡɛn. hi ɹeɪzd ə mɑnjəmən ðəɹ tə hɪz vɪktɝi, ə spaɪɹ ə hʌnʒɹəd spænz haɪ. hi wəd nɑt lɛɾ əm pʊɾ ɪz oʊn neɪm ɑn ɪt, bʌt ɹæðɝ ðə neɪmz ʌv ɛvɹi mæn u fɛl, ən ə ɡoʊldən sʌn ət ðə tɑp, sɪmbəl ðət ðəɹ ðə laɪt hæd tʃɹaɪəmft oʊvɝ ðə ʃædoʊ."

"We will reach the field of Talidar in three or four days at this rate," Ingtar said as they rode. "Artur Hawkwing's greatest single victory, when the Halfmen led the Trollocs out of the Blight against him. Six days and nights, it lasted, and when it was done, the Trollocs fled back into the Blight and never dared challenge him again. He raised a monument there to his victory, a spire a hundred spans high. He would not let them put his own name on it, but rather the names of every man who fell, and a golden sun at the top, symbol that there the Light had triumphed over the Shadow."

"aɪ wəd laɪk tə si ðæt," lɔɪəl sɛd. "aɪ hæv nɛvɝ hɝɾ ə ðɪs mɑnjəmənt."

"I would like to see that," Loial said. "I have never heard of this monument."

ɪŋtʃɹ wɑz saɪlən fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ən wən i spoʊk ɪz vɔɪs wɑz kwaɪət. "ɪɾ ɪz nɑt ðəɹ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ, bɪldɝ. wən hɔkwɪŋ daɪd, ðə wʌnz u fɔɾ oʊvɝ ɪz ɛmpaɪɝ kəd nɑt bɛɹ tə liv ə mɑnjəmən tə ə vɪktɝi ʌv hɪz, ivən ɪf ɪt dɪd nɑt mɛnʃən ɪz neɪm. ðɛɹz nʌθɪŋ lɛf bʌt ðə maʊnd wɛɹ ɪt stʊd. ɪn θɹi əɹ fɔɹ deɪz wi kən si ðæt, ət list." hɪz toʊn dɪd nɑɾ əlaʊ mʌtʃ kɑnvɝseɪʃən æftɝwɝdz.

Ingtar was silent for a moment, and when he spoke his voice was quiet. "It is not there any longer, Builder. When Hawkwing died, the ones who fought over his empire could not bear to leave a monument to a victory of his, even if it did not mention his name. There's nothing left but the mound where it stood. In three or four days we can see that, at least." His tone did not allow much conversation afterwards.

wɪð ðə sʌn hæŋɪŋ ɡoʊldən oʊvɝhɛd, ðeɪ pæst ə stʃɹʌktʃɝ, skwɛɹ ən meɪɾ ə plæstɝd bɹɪk, lɛs ðən ə maɪl fɹəm ðɛɹ pæθ. ɪt wɑz nɑt tɔl, noʊ mɔɹ ðən tu stɔɹiz stɪl stændɪŋ ɛniwɛɹ i sɔ, bʌɾ ɪt kʌvɝɾ ə ɡʊd haɪɾ ʌv ɡɹaʊnd. ən ɛɹ ə lɔŋ əbændənmən hʌŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt, ɹufs ɡɔn ɪksɛp fəɹ ə fju stʃɹɛtʃəz ə dɑɹk taɪl klɪŋɪŋ tə bɪts ə ɹæftɝ, moʊst ə ðə wʌns-waɪt plæstɝ fɔlən tə bɛɹ ðə dɑɹk, wɛðɝd bɹɪk bɪniθ, wɔlz fɔlən tə ʃoʊ kɔɹtʃjɑɹdz ən dəkeɪɪŋ tʃeɪmbɝz ɪnsaɪd. bɹʌʃ, ən ivən tʃɹiz, ɡɹu ɪn ðə kɹæks ʌv wʌt hæd wʌns bɪn kɔɹtʃjɑɹdz.

With the sun hanging golden overhead, they passed a structure, square and made of plastered brick, less than a mile from their path. It was not tall, no more than two stories still standing anywhere he saw, but it covered a good hide of ground. An air of long abandonment hung about it, roofs gone except for a few stretches of dark tile clinging to bits of rafter, most of the once-white plaster fallen to bare the dark, weathered brick beneath, walls fallen to show courtyards and decaying chambers inside. Brush, and even trees, grew in the cracks of what had once been courtyards.

"ə mænɝ haʊs," ɪŋtʃɹ ɪkspleɪnd. ðə lɪɾəl hjumɝ i hæd ɹiɡeɪn sim tə feɪɾ əz i lʊkt ət ðə stʃɹʌktʃɝ. "wɛn hɑɹəd dɑkɑɹ stɪl stʊd, aɪ ɪkspɛk ðə mænɔɹmən fɑɹm ðɪs læn fəɹ ə liɡ ɝaʊnd. ɔɹtʃɝdz, meɪbi. ðə hɑɹdɑni lʌv ðɛɹ ɔɹtʃɝdz."

"A manor house," Ingtar explained. The little humor he had regained seemed to fade as he looked at the structure. "When Harad Dakar still stood, I expect the manorman farmed this land for a league around. Orchards, maybe. The Hardani loved their orchards."

"hɑɹəd dɑkɑɹ?" ɹænd sɛd, ən ɪŋtʃɹ snɔɹɾɪd.

"Harad Dakar?" Rand said, and Ingtar snorted.

"dʌz noʊ wʌn lɝn hɪstɝi ɛni lɔŋɡɝ? hɑɹəd dɑkɑɹ, ðə kæpəɾəl sɪɾi ʌv hɑɹɾən, wɪtʃ neɪʃən ðɪs wʌns wɑz ðət wəɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ əkɹɔs."

"Does no one learn history any longer? Harad Dakar, the capital city of Hardan, which nation this once was that we are riding across."

"aɪv sin ən oʊl mæp," ɹænd ɹɪplaɪɾ ɪn ə taɪt vɔɪs. "aɪ noʊ əbaʊt ðə neɪʃənz ðəɾ ɑɹən ðəɹ ɛnimɔɹ. mɑɹeɪɾoʊ, ən ɡoʊbən, ən kæɹələn. bʌt ðəɹ wɑzn ɛni hɑɹɾən ɑn ɪt."

"I've seen an old map," Rand replied in a tight voice. "I know about the nations that aren't there anymore. Maredo, and Goaban, and Caralain. But there wasn't any Hardan on it."

"ðɛɹ wɝ wʌns ʌðɝz ðəɾ ɑɹ ɡɔn naʊ, tu," lɔɪəl sɛd. "mɑɹ hæɾən, wɪtʃ ɪz naʊ hæɾən mɝk, ən ɑlməθ. kintɑɹə. ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz kʌɾ ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz ɛmpaɪɝ ɪndə mɛni neɪʃənz, lɑɹdʒ ən smɔl. ðə smɔl wɝ ɡɑbəld ʌp baɪ ðə lɑɹdʒ, əɹ ɛls junaɪɾəd, laɪk ɔltɑɹə ən mʊɹændi. fɔɹs təɡɛðɝ wəd bi ə bɛɾɝ wɝd ðən junaɪɾəd, aɪ səpoʊz."

"There were once others that are gone now, too," Loial said. "Mar Haddon, which is now Haddon Mirk, and Almoth. Kintara. The War of the Hundred Years cut Artur Hawkwing's empire into many nations, large and small. The small were gobbled up by the large, or else united, like Altara and Murandy. Forced together would be a better word than united, I suppose."

"soʊ wʌt hæpən tə ðɛm?" mæt dɪmændəd. ɹænd hæd nɑt noʊɾəst pɛɹɪn ən mæt ɹaɪɾ ʌp tə dʒɔɪn ðɛm. ðeɪ hæd bɪn ət ðə ɹɪɹ, əz fɑɹ fɹəm ɹænd ælθɹ əz ðeɪ kəd ɡɛt, ðə læst i hæd sin.

"So what happened to them?" Mat demanded. Rand had not noticed Perrin and Mat ride up to join them. They had been at the rear, as far from Rand al'Thor as they could get, the last he had seen.

"ðeɪ kəd nɑt hoʊl təɡɛðɝ," ði oʊɡiɝ ɹɪplaɪd. "kɹɑps feɪld, əɹ tʃɹeɪd feɪld. pipəl feɪld. sʌmθɪŋ feɪld ɪn itʃ keɪs, ən ðə neɪʃən dwɪndəld. ɔfən neɪbɝɪŋ kʌntʃɹiz əbzɔɹb ðə lænd, wən ðə neɪʃənz wɝ ɡɔn, bʌt ðeɪ nɛvɝ læstəd, ðoʊz ænɛkseɪʃənz. ɪn taɪm, ðə læn tʃɹuli wɑz əbændənd. səm vɪlədʒəz hæŋ ɑn hɪɹ ən ðɛɹ, bʌt moʊsli ðeɪv ɔl ɡɔn tə wɪldɝnəs. ɪts nɪɹli θɹi hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz sɪns hɑɹəd dɑkɑɹ wɑz faɪnəli əbændənd, bʌɾ ivən bɪfɔɹ ðəɾ ɪt wɑz ə ʃɛl, wɪð ə kɪŋ u kəd nɑt kəntʃɹoʊl wʌt hæpən ɪnsaɪd ðə sɪɾi wɔlz. hɑɹəd dɑkɑɹ ɪtsɛlf ɪz kəmplitli ɡɔn naʊ, aɪ ʌndɝstænd. ɔl ðə taʊnz ən sɪɾiz ə hɑɹɾən ɑɹ ɡɔn, ðə stoʊn kɑɹɾɪd əweɪ baɪ fɑɹmɝz ən vɪlɪdʒɝz fəɹ ðɛɹ oʊn juz. moʊst ə ðə fɑɹmz ən vɪlədʒəz meɪd wɪð ɪɾ ɑɹ ɡɔn, tu. soʊ aɪ ɹɛd, ən aɪv sin nʌθɪŋ tə tʃeɪnʒ ɪt."

"They could not hold together," the Ogier replied. "Crops failed, or trade failed. People failed. Something failed in each case, and the nation dwindled. Often neighboring countries absorbed the land, when the nations were gone, but they never lasted, those annexations. In time, the land truly was abandoned. Some villages hang on here and there, but mostly they have all gone to wilderness. It is nearly three hundred years since Harad Dakar was finally abandoned, but even before that it was a shell, with a king who could not control what happened inside the city walls. Harad Dakar itself is completely gone now, I understand. All the towns and cities of Hardan are gone, the stone carted away by farmers and villagers for their own use. Most of the farms and villages made with it are gone, too. So I read, and I've seen nothing to change it."

"ɪt wɑz kwaɪɾ ə kwɔɹi, hɑɹəd dɑkɑɹ, fəɹ ɔlmoʊst ə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd bɪɾɝli. "ðə pipəl lɛft, faɪnəli, ən ðən ðə sɪɾi wɑz hɔld əweɪ, stoʊn baɪ stoʊn. ɔl feɪɾəd əweɪ, ən wʌɾ əz nɑt ɡɔn ɪz feɪɾɪŋ. ɛvɹiθɪŋ, ɛvɹiwɛɹ, feɪɾɪŋ. ðəɹ ɪz hɑɹdli ə neɪʃən ðət tʃɹuli kəntʃɹoʊlz ðə læn ɪt kleɪmz ɑn ə mæp, ən ðəɹ ɪz hɑɹdli ə læn ðət kleɪmz tədeɪ ɑn ə mæp wʌɾ ɪt dɪɾ ivən ə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz əɡoʊ. wən ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz ɛndəd, ə mæn ɹoʊd fɹəm wʌn neɪʃən ɪndə ənʌðɝ wɪθaʊɾ ɛn fɹəm ðə blaɪt tə ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz. naʊ wi kən ɹaɪd θɹu wɪldɝnəs kleɪm baɪ noʊ neɪʃən fəɹ ɔlmoʊs ðə hoʊl ə ðə lænd. wi ɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz əv əɹ bæɾəl wɪð ðə blaɪt tə kip əs stʃɹɔŋ, ən hoʊl. pɝhæps ðeɪ dɪd nɑɾ əv wʌt ðeɪ niɾəd tə kip əm stʃɹɔŋ. jə seɪ ðeɪ feɪld, bɪldɝ? jɛs, ðeɪ feɪld, ən wʌt neɪʃən stændɪŋ hoʊl tədeɪ wɪl feɪl təmɑɹoʊ? wəɹ biɪŋ swɛpt əweɪ, hjumənkaɪnd. swɛpt əweɪ laɪk flɑtsəm ɑn ə flʌd. haʊ lɔŋ əntɪl ðəɹ ɪz nʌθɪŋ lɛf bʌt ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz? haʊ lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ wi, tu, ɡoʊ ʌndɝ, ən ðəɹ ɪz nʌθɪŋ lɛf bʌt tʃɹɑləks ən mɹdʒɹɑl ɔl ðə weɪ tə ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz?"

"It was quite a quarry, Harad Dakar, for almost a hundred years," Ingtar said bitterly. "The people left, finally, and then the city was hauled away, stone by stone. All faded away, and what has not gone is fading. Everything, everywhere, fading. There is hardly a nation that truly controls the land it claims on a map, and there is hardly a land that claims today on a map what it did even a hundred years ago. When the War of the Hundred Years ended, a man rode from one nation into another without end from the Blight to the Sea of Storms. Now we can ride through wilderness claimed by no nation for almost the whole of the land. We in the Borderlands have our battle with the Blight to keep us strong, and whole. Perhaps they did not have what they needed to keep them strong. You say they failed, Builder? Yes, they failed, and what nation standing whole today will fail tomorrow? We are being swept away, humankind. Swept away like flotsam on a flood. How long until there is nothing left but the Borderlands? How long before we, too, go under, and there is nothing left but Trollocs and Myrddraal all the way to the Sea of Storms?"

ðəɹ wɑz ə ʃɑk saɪləns. nɑɾ ivən mæt bɹoʊk ɪt. ɪŋtʃɹ ɹoʊd lɔst ɪn ɪz oʊn dɑɹk θɔts.

There was a shocked silence. Not even Mat broke it. Ingtar rode lost in his own dark thoughts.

æftɝ ə taɪm ðə skaʊts keɪm ɡæləpɪŋ bæk, stʃɹeɪɾ ɪn ðə sæɾəlz, lænsɪz ɪɹɛkt əɡɛns ðə skaɪ. "ə vɪlədʒ əhɛd, maɪ lɔɹd. wi wɝ nɑt sin, bʌɾ ɪt laɪz dɝɛkli ɪn əɹ laɪn ə mɑɹtʃ."

After a time the scouts came galloping back, straight in the saddles, lances erect against the sky. "A village ahead, my Lord. We were not seen, but it lies directly in our line of march."

ɪŋtʃɹ ʃʊk hɪmsɛlf aʊɾ ə hɪz bɹaʊn stʌɾi, bʌt dɪd nɑt spik əntɪl ðeɪ hæd ɹitʃt ðə kɹɛst ʌv ə loʊ ɹɪdʒ lʊkɪŋ daʊn ɑn ðə vɪlədʒ, ən ðən ɪt wɑz oʊnli tə kəmæn ə hɔlt waɪl i dʌɡ ə lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs fɹəm ɪz sæɾəlbæɡz ən ɹeɪzd ɪt tə pɪɹ ət ðə vɪlədʒ.

Ingtar shook himself out of his brown study, but did not speak until they had reached the crest of a low ridge looking down on the village, and then it was only to command a halt while he dug a looking glass from his saddlebags and raised it to peer at the village.

ɹænd stʌɾid ðə vɪlədʒ wɪð ɪntʃɹəst. ɪt wɑz əz bɪɡ əz ɛmənz fild, ðoʊ ðət wɑz nɑt vɛɹi bɪɡ kəmpɛɹd tə səm ə ðə taʊnz i hæd sin sɪns livɪŋ ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, mʌtʃ lɛs ðə sɪɾiz. ðə haʊsəz wɝ ɔl loʊ ən plæstɝd wɪð waɪt kleɪ, ən ðeɪ əpɪɹd tə hæv ɡɹæs ɡɹoʊɪŋ ɑn sloʊpɪŋ ɹufs. ə dʌzən wɪndmɪlz, skæɾɝd θɹu ðə vɪlədʒ, tɝn læzəli, ðɛɹ lɔŋ, klɔθ-kʌvɝɾ ɑɹmz flæʃɪŋ waɪɾ ɪn ðə sʌn. ə loʊ wɔl ɪnsɝkəl ðə vɪlədʒ, ɡɹæsi dɝɾ ən tʃɛs haɪ, ən aʊtsaɪd ðət wɑz ə waɪd dɪtʃ wɪð ʃɑɹpən steɪks θɪk ɪn ðə bɑɾəm. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɡeɪɾ ɪn ðə wʌn oʊpənɪŋ i kəd si ɪn ðə wɔl, bʌɾ i səpoʊzd ɪt kəd bi blɑkt izəli ɪnʌf wɪð ə kɑɹɾ əɹ wæɡən. hi kəd nɑt si ɛni pipəl.

Rand studied the village with interest. It was as big as Emond's Field, though that was not very big compared to some of the towns he had seen since leaving the Two Rivers, much less the cities. The houses were all low and plastered with white clay, and they appeared to have grass growing on sloping roofs. A dozen windmills, scattered through the village, turned lazily, their long, cloth-covered arms flashing white in the sun. A low wall encircled the village, grassy dirt and chest high, and outside that was a wide ditch with sharpened stakes thick in the bottom. There was no gate in the one opening he could see in the wall, but he supposed it could be blocked easily enough with a cart or wagon. He could not see any people.

"nɑɾ ivən ə dɔɡ ɪn saɪt," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd, ɹɪtɝnɪŋ ðə lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs tə hɪz sæɾəlbæɡz. "ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ ðeɪ dɪd nɑt si ju?" hi æsk ðə skaʊts.

"Not even a dog in sight," Ingtar said, returning the looking glass to his saddlebags. "Are you sure they did not see you?" he asked the scouts.

"nɑɾ ənlɛs ðeɪv ðə dɑɹk wʌnz oʊn lʌk, maɪ lɔɹd," wʌn ə ðə mɛn ɹɪplaɪd. "wi nɛvɝ kɹɛstəd ðə ɹaɪz. wi dɪdn si ɛniwʌn muvɪŋ ðən iðɝ, maɪ lɔɹd."

"Not unless they have the Dark One's own luck, my Lord," one of the men replied. "We never crested the rise. We didn't see anyone moving then either, my Lord."

ɪŋtʃɹ nɑɾəd. "ðə tʃɹeɪl, hʊɹɪn?"

Ingtar nodded. "The trail, Hurin?"

hʊɹɪn dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ. "təwɔɹd ðə vɪlədʒ, maɪ lɔɹd. stʃɹeɪt tə ɪt, əz nɪɹ əz aɪ kən tɛl fɹəm hɪɹ."

Hurin drew a deep breath. "Toward the village, my Lord. Straight to it, as near as I can tell from here."

"wɑtʃ ʃɑɹp," ɪŋtʃɹ kəmændəd, ɡæðɝɪŋ ɪz ɹeɪnz. "æn də nɑt bɪliv ðət ðəɹ fɹɛnli dʒʌs kəz ðeɪ smaɪl. ɪf ðəɹ ɪz ɛniwʌn ðɛɹ." hi lɛɾ əm daʊn təwɔɹd ðə vɪlədʒ əɾ ə sloʊ wɔk, ən ɹitʃt ʌp tə lusən ɪz sɔɹɾ ɪn ɪts skæbɝd.

"Watch sharp," Ingtar commanded, gathering his reins. "And do not believe that they're friendly just because they smile. If there is anyone there." He led them down toward the village at a slow walk, and reached up to loosen his sword in its scabbard.

ɹænd hɝd ðə saʊnz ʌv ʌðɝz bɪhaɪn ɪm duɪŋ ðə seɪm. æftɝ ə moʊmənt, hi iz hɪz, tu. tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə steɪ əlaɪv wɑz nɑt ðə seɪm əz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə bi ə hɪɹoʊ, hi dɪsaɪɾɪd.

Rand heard the sounds of others behind him doing the same. After a moment, he eased his, too. Trying to stay alive was not the same as trying to be a hero, he decided.

"ju θɪŋk ðiz pipəl wəd hɛlp dɑɹkfɹɛnz?" pɛɹɪn æskt ɪŋtʃɹ. ðə ʃaɪnɝən wɑz sloʊ ɪn ænsɝɪŋ.

"You think these people would help Darkfriends?" Perrin asked Ingtar. The Shienaran was slow in answering.

"ðeɪ hæv noʊ ɡɹeɪt lʌv fəɹ ʃaɪnɝənz," hi sɛd faɪnəli. "ðeɪ θɪŋk wi ʃəd pɹətɛk ðɛm. ʌs, əɹ ðə kɛɹhinɪn. kɛɹhin dɪd kleɪm ðɪs lænd, wʌns ðə læs kɪŋ ə hɑɹɾən daɪd. ɔl ðə weɪ tə ði ɛɹɪnɪn, ðeɪ kleɪmd ɪt. ðeɪ kəd nɑt hoʊld ɪt, ðoʊ. ðeɪ ɡeɪv ʌp ðə kleɪm nɪɹli ə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz əɡoʊ. ðə fju pipəl u stɪl laɪv hɪɹ doʊn əv tə wɝi əbaʊt tʃɹɑləks ðɪs fɑɹ saʊθ, bʌt ðəɹ ɑɹ plɛnti ʌv hjumən bɹɪɡænz. ðæts waɪ ðeɪv ðə wɔl, ən ðə dɪtʃ. ɔl ðɛɹ vɪlədʒəz du. ðɛɹ filz wɪl bi hɪɾən ɪn hɑloʊz ɝaʊn hɪɹ, bʌt noʊ wʌn wɪl lɪv aʊtsaɪd ðə wɔl. ðeɪ wəd swɛɹ fiəlti tə ɛni kɪŋ u wəd ɡɪv əm ɪz pɹətɛkʃən, bʌt wɪv ɔl wi kən də əɡɛns ðə tʃɹɑləks. ðeɪ də nɑt lʌv əs fəɹ ɪt, ðoʊ." əz ðeɪ ɹitʃt ði oʊpənɪŋ ɪn ðə loʊ wɔl, hi æɾəd əɡɛn, "wɑtʃ ʃɑɹp!"

"They have no great love for Shienarans," he said finally. "They think we should protect them. Us, or the Cairhienin. Cairhien did claim this land, once the last King of Hardan died. All the way to the Erinin, they claimed it. They could not hold it, though. They gave up the claim nearly a hundred years ago. The few people who still live here don't have to worry about Trollocs this far south, but there are plenty of human brigands. That's why they have the wall, and the ditch. All their villages do. Their fields will be hidden in hollows around here, but no one will live outside the wall. They would swear fealty to any king who would give them his protection, but we have all we can do against the Trollocs. They do not love us for it, though." As they reached the opening in the low wall, he added again, "Watch sharp!"

ɔl ðə stʃɹits lɛd təwɔɹɾ ə vɪlədʒ skwɛɹ, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ wʌn ɪn ðə stʃɹits, noʊ wʌn piɹɪŋ fɹəm ə wɪndoʊ. nɑɾ ivən ə dɔɡ muvd, nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə tʃɪkən. nʌθɪŋ lɪvɪŋ. oʊpən dɔɹz swʌŋ, kɹikɪŋ ɪn ðə wɪnd, kaʊntɝpɔɪn tə ðə ɹɪðmɪk skwik ə ðə wɪndmɪlz. ðə hɔɹsəz' hʊvz saʊndəd laʊɾ ɑn ðə pæk dɝɾ ə ðə stʃɹit.

All the streets led toward a village square, but there was no one in the streets, no one peering from a window. Not even a dog moved, not so much as a chicken. Nothing living. Open doors swung, creaking in the wind, counterpoint to the rhythmic squeak of the windmills. The horses' hooves sounded loud on the packed dirt of the street.

"laɪk ət ðə fɛɹi," hʊɹɪn mʌɾɝd, "bʌt dɪfɹənt." hi ɹoʊd hʌntʃt ɪn ɪz sæɾəl, hɛd daʊn əz ɪf i wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə haɪd bɪhaɪn ɪz oʊn ʃoʊldɝz. "vaɪələns dʌn, bʌt . . . aɪ doʊnt noʊ. ɪt wɑz bæd hɪɹ. ɪt smɛlz bæd."

"Like at the ferry," Hurin muttered, "but different." He rode hunched in his saddle, head down as if he were trying to hide behind his own shoulders. "Violence done, but . . . I don't know. It was bad here. It smells bad."

"ənoʊ," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd, "teɪk wʌn faɪl ən sɝtʃ ðə haʊsəz. ɪf jə faɪn ɛniwʌn, bɹɪŋ əm tə mi ɪn ðə skwɛɹ. də nɑt fɹaɪɾən əm ðɪs taɪm, ðoʊ. aɪ wɑn ænsɝz, nɑt pipəl ɹʌnɪŋ fəɹ ðɛɹ lɪvz." hi lɛd ði ʌðɝ soʊlʒɝz təwɔɹd ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə vɪlədʒ əz ənoʊ ɡɑɾ ɪz tɛn dɪsmaʊntɪd.

"Uno," Ingtar said, "take one file and search the houses. If you find anyone, bring them to me in the square. Do not frighten them this time, though. I want answers, not people running for their lives." He led the other soldiers toward the center of the village as Uno got his ten dismounted.

ɹænd hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, lʊkɪŋ ɝaʊnd. ðə kɹikɪŋ dɔɹz, ðə skwilɪŋ wɪndmɪlz, ðə hɔɹsəz' hʊvz, ɔl meɪd tu mʌtʃ nɔɪz, əz ɪf ðəɹ wɝ nɑɾ ənʌðɝ saʊn ɪn ðə wɝld. hi skæn ðə haʊsəz. ðə kɝɾənz ɪn ən oʊpən wɪndoʊ biɾ əɡɛns ði aʊtsaɪɾ ə ðə haʊs. ðeɪ ɔl sim laɪfləs. wɪð ə saɪ hi ɡɑt daʊn ən wɔk tə ðə nɪɹəs haʊs, ðən stɑpt, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə dɔɹ.

Rand hesitated, looking around. The creaking doors, the squealing windmills, the horses' hooves, all made too much noise, as if there were not another sound in the world. He scanned the houses. The curtains in an open window beat against the outside of the house. They all seemed lifeless. With a sigh he got down and walked to the nearest house, then stopped, staring at the door.

ɪts dʒʌst ə dɔɹ. wʌɾ ɑɹ jə əfɹeɪɾ ʌv? hi wɪʃt i dɪd nɑt fil əz ɪf ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ weɪɾɪŋ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd. hi pʊʃt ɪɾ oʊpən.

It's just a door. What are you afraid of? He wished he did not feel as if there was something waiting on the other side. He pushed it open.

ɪnsaɪd wɑz ə taɪɾi ɹum. əɹ hæd bɪn. ðə teɪbəl wɑz sɛt fəɹ ə mil, læɾɝ-bæk tʃɛɹz ɡæðɝɾ ɝaʊnd, səm pleɪts ɔlɹɛɾi sɝvd. ə fju flaɪz bʌzd əbʌv boʊlz ə tɝnəps ən piz, ən mɔɹ kɹɔld ɑn ə koʊld ɹoʊst sɪɾɪŋ ɪn ɪts oʊn kəndʒild ɡɹis. ðəɹ wɑz ə slaɪs hæf kɑɹv fɹəm ðə ɹoʊst, ðə fɔɹk stɪl stændɪŋ stʌk ɪn ðə miɾ ən ðə kɑɹvɪŋ naɪf laɪɪŋ pɑɹtweɪ ɪn ðə plæɾɝ əz ɪf dʒɹɑpt. ɹænd stɛpt ɪnsaɪd.

Inside was a tidy room. Or had been. The table was set for a meal, ladder-back chairs gathered around, some plates already served. A few flies buzzed above bowls of turnips and peas, and more crawled on a cold roast sitting in its own congealed grease. There was a slice half carved from the roast, the fork still standing stuck in the meat and the carving knife lying partway in the platter as if dropped. Rand stepped inside.

blɪŋk.

Blink.

ə smaɪlɪŋ, bɔld-hɛɾəd mæn ɪn ɹʌf kloʊðz leɪɾ ə slaɪs ə miɾ ɑn ə pleɪt hɛl baɪ ə wʊmən wɪð ə wɔɹn feɪs. ʃi wɑz smaɪlɪŋ, tu, ðoʊ. ʃi æɾəd piz ən tɝnəps tə ðə pleɪɾ ən pæst ɪt tə wʌn ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən laɪnɪŋ ðə teɪbəl. ðəɹ wɝ hæf ə dʌzən tʃɪlʒɹən, bɔɪz ən ɡɝlz, fɹəm nɪɹli ɡɹoʊn daʊn tə bɛɹli tɔl ɪnʌf tə lʊk oʊvɝ ðə teɪbəl. ðə wʊmən sɛd sʌmθɪŋ, ən ðə ɡɝl teɪkɪŋ ðə pleɪt fɹəm əɹ læft. ðə mæn stɑɹɾəd tə kʌɾ ənʌðɝ slaɪs.

A smiling, bald-headed man in rough clothes laid a slice of meat on a plate held by a woman with a worn face. She was smiling, too, though. She added peas and turnips to the plate and passed it to one of the children lining the table. There were half a dozen children, boys and girls, from nearly grown down to barely tall enough to look over the table. The woman said something, and the girl taking the plate from her laughed. The man started to cut another slice.

sʌɾənli ənʌðɝ ɡɝl skɹimd, pɔɪntɪŋ ət ðə dɔɹ tə ðə stʃɹit. ðə mæn dʒɹɑp ðə kɑɹvɪŋ naɪf ən wɝld, ðən i skɹimd, tu, feɪs taɪt wɪð hɔɹɝ, ən snætʃt ʌp ə tʃaɪld. ðə wʊmən ɡɹæbd ənʌðɝ, ən moʊʃən dɛspɝətli tə ði ʌðɝz, hɝ maʊθ wɝkɪŋ fɹæntəkəli, saɪlənli. ðeɪ ɔl skɹæbəl təwɔɹɾ ə dɔɹ ɪn ðə bæk ə ðə ɹum.

Suddenly another girl screamed, pointing at the door to the street. The man dropped the carving knife and whirled, then he screamed, too, face tight with horror, and snatched up a child. The woman grabbed another, and motioned desperately to the others, her mouth working frantically, silently. They all scrabbled toward a door in the back of the room.

ðət dɔɹ bɝst oʊpən, ən -  blɪŋk.

That door burst open, and -  Blink.

ɹænd kəd nɑt muv. ðə flaɪz bʌzɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə teɪbəl saʊndəd laʊɾɝ. hɪz bɹɛθ meɪɾ ə klaʊɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪz maʊθ.

Rand could not move. The flies buzzing over the table sounded louder. His breath made a cloud in front of his mouth.

blɪŋk.

Blink.

ə smaɪlɪŋ, bɔld-hɛɾəd mæn ɪn ɹʌf kloʊðz leɪɾ ə slaɪs ə miɾ ɑn ə pleɪt hɛl baɪ ə wʊmən wɪð ə wɔɹn feɪs. ʃi wɑz smaɪlɪŋ, tu, ðoʊ. ʃi æɾəd piz ən tɝnəps tə ðə pleɪɾ ən pæst ɪt tə wʌn ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən laɪnɪŋ ðə teɪbəl. ðəɹ wɝ hæf ə dʌzən tʃɪlʒɹən, bɔɪz ən ɡɝlz, fɹəm nɪɹli ɡɹoʊn daʊn tə bɛɹli tɔl ɪnʌf tə lʊk oʊvɝ ðə teɪbəl. ðə wʊmən sɛd sʌmθɪŋ, ən ðə ɡɝl teɪkɪŋ ðə pleɪt fɹəm əɹ læft. ðə mæn stɑɹɾəd tə kʌɾ ənʌðɝ slaɪs.

She added peas and turnips to the plate and passed it to one of the children lining the table. There were half a dozen children, boys and girls, from nearly grown down to barely tall enough to look over the table. The woman said something, and the girl taking the plate from her laughed. The man started to cut another slice.

sʌɾənli ənʌðɝ ɡɝl skɹimd, pɔɪntɪŋ ət ðə dɔɹ tə ðə stʃɹit. ðə mæn dʒɹɑp ðə kɑɹvɪŋ naɪf ən wɝld, ðən i skɹimd, tu, feɪs taɪt wɪð hɔɹɝ, ən snætʃt ʌp ə tʃaɪld. ðə wʊmən ɡɹæbd ənʌðɝ, ən moʊʃən dɛspɝətli tə ði ʌðɝz, hɝ maʊθ wɝkɪŋ fɹæntəkəli, saɪlənli. ðeɪ ɔl skɹæbəl təwɔɹd ðə dɔɹ ɪn ðə bæk ə ðə ɹum.

Suddenly another girl screamed, pointing at the door to the street. The man dropped the carving knife and whirled, then he screamed, too, face tight with horror, and snatched up a child. The woman grabbed another, and motioned desperately to the others, her mouth working frantically, silently. They all scrabbled toward the door in the back of the room.

ðət dɔɹ bɝst oʊpən, ən -  blɪŋk.

That door burst open, and -  Blink.

ɹænd stʃɹʌɡəld, bʌɾ ɪz mʌsəlz sim fɹoʊzən. ðə ɹum wɑz koʊldɝ; hi wɑntəd tə ʃɪvɝ, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt muv ivən ðət mʌtʃ. flaɪz kɹɔld ɔl oʊvɝ ðə teɪbəl. hi ɡɹoʊp fəɹ ðə vɔɪd. ðə saʊɝ laɪt wɑz ðɛɹ, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt kɛɹ. hi hæd tə -  blɪŋk.

Rand struggled, but his muscles seemed frozen. The room was colder; he wanted to shiver, but he could not move even that much. Flies crawled all over the table. He groped for the void. The sour light was there, but he did not care. He had to -  Blink.

ə smaɪlɪŋ, bɔld-hɛɾəd mæn ɪn ɹʌf kloʊðz leɪɾ ə slaɪs ə miɾ ɑn ə pleɪt hɛl baɪ ə wʊmən wɪð ə wɔɹn feɪs. ʃi wɑz smaɪlɪŋ, tu, ðoʊ. ʃi æɾəd piz ən tɝnəps tə ðə pleɪɾ ən pæst ɪt tə wʌn ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən laɪnɪŋ ðə teɪbəl. ðəɹ wɝ hæf ə dʌzən tʃɪlʒɹən, bɔɪz ən ɡɝlz, fɹəm nɪɹli ɡɹoʊn daʊn tə bɛɹli tɔl ɪnʌf tə lʊk oʊvɝ ðə teɪbəl. ðə wʊmən sɛd sʌmθɪŋ, ən ðə ɡɝl teɪkɪŋ ðə pleɪt fɹəm əɹ læft. ðə mæn stɑɹɾəd tə kʌɾ ənʌðɝ slaɪs.

A smiling, bald-headed man in rough clothes laid a slice of meat on a plate held by a woman with a worn face. She was smiling, too, though. She added peas and turnips to the plate and passed it to one of the children lining the table. There were half a dozen children, boys and girls, from nearly grown down to barely tall enough to look over the table. The woman said something, and the girl taking the plate from her laughed. The man started to cut another slice.

sʌɾənli ənʌðɝ ɡɝl skɹimd, pɔɪntɪŋ ət ðə dɔɹ tə ðə stʃɹit. ðə mæn dʒɹɑp ðə kɑɹvɪŋ naɪf ən wɝld, ðən i skɹimd, tu, feɪs taɪt wɪð hɔɹɝ, ən snætʃt ʌp ə tʃaɪld. ðə wʊmən ɡɹæbd ənʌðɝ, ən moʊʃən dɛspɝətli tə ði ʌðɝz, hɝ maʊθ wɝkɪŋ fɹæntəkəli, saɪlənli. ðeɪ ɔl skɹæbəl təwɔɹɾ ə dɔɹ ɪn ðə bæk ə ðə ɹum.

Suddenly another girl screamed, pointing at the door to the street. The man dropped the carving knife and whirled, then he screamed, too, face tight with horror, and snatched up a child. The woman grabbed another, and motioned desperately to the others, her mouth working frantically, silently. They all scrabbled toward a door in the back of the room.

ðət dɔɹ bɝst oʊpən, ən -  blɪŋk.

That door burst open, and -  Blink.

ðə ɹum wɑz fɹizɪŋ. soʊ koʊld. flaɪz blækən ðə teɪbəl; ðə wɔlz wɝ ə ʃɪftɪŋ mæs ə flaɪz, ðə flɔɹ, ðə silɪŋ, ɔl blæk wɪð ðɛm. ðeɪ kɹɔld ɑn ɹænd, kʌvɝɪŋ hɪm, kɹɔld oʊvɝ ɪz feɪs, hɪz aɪz, ɪndə hɪz noʊz, hɪz maʊθ. laɪt, hɛlp mi. koʊld. ðə flaɪz bʌz laɪk θʌndɝ. koʊld. ɪt pɛnətʃɹeɪɾəd ðə vɔɪd, mɑkɪŋ ði ɛmptinəs, ɛnkəsɪŋ ɪm ɪn aɪs. dɛspɝətli hi ɹitʃt fəɹ ðə flɪkɝɪŋ laɪt. hɪz stʌmək twɪstəd, bʌt ðə laɪt wɑz wɔɹm. wɔɹm. hɑt. hi wɑz hɑt.

The room was freezing. So cold. Flies blackened the table; the walls were a shifting mass of flies, the floor, the ceiling, all black with them. They crawled on Rand, covering him, crawled over his face, his eyes, into his nose, his mouth. Light, help me. Cold. The flies buzzed like thunder. Cold. It penetrated the void, mocking the emptiness, encasing him in ice. Desperately he reached for the flickering light. His stomach twisted, but the light was warm. Warm. Hot. He was hot.

sʌɾənli hi wɑz tɛɹɪŋ ət . . . sʌmθɪŋ. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt, əɹ haʊ. kɑbwɛbz meɪɾ ə stil. munbimz kɑɹv fɹəm stoʊn. ðeɪ kɹʌmbəld əɾ ɪz tʌtʃ, bʌɾ i nu hi hæd nɑt tʌtʃt ɛniθɪŋ. ðeɪ ʃɹɪvəld ən mɛltəd wɪð ðə hit ðət sɝdʒ θɹu hɪm, hit laɪk ə fɔɹdʒ faɪɝ, hit laɪk ðə wɝl bɝnɪŋ, hit laɪk -  ɪt wɑz ɡɔn. pæntɪŋ, hi lʊkt ɝaʊnd wɪð waɪɾ aɪz. ə fju flaɪz leɪ ɑn ðə hæf-kɑɹvd ɹoʊst, ɪn ðə plæɾɝ. dɛd flaɪz. sɪks flaɪz. oʊnli sɪks. ðəɹ wɝ mɔɹ ɪn ðə boʊlz, hæf ə dʌzən taɪni blæk spɛks əmʌŋ ðə koʊl vɛdʒtəbəlz. ɔl dɛd. hi stæɡɝɾ aʊɾ ɪndə ðə stʃɹit.

Suddenly he was tearing at . . . something. He did not know what, or how. Cobwebs made of steel. Moonbeams carved from stone. They crumbled at his touch, but he knew he had not touched anything. They shriveled and melted with the heat that surged through him, heat like a forge fire, heat like the world burning, heat like -  It was gone. Panting, he looked around with wide eyes. A few flies lay on the half-carved roast, in the platter. Dead flies. Six flies. Only six. There were more in the bowls, half a dozen tiny black specks among the cold vegetables. All dead. He staggered out into the street.

mæt wɑz dʒʌs kʌmɪŋ aʊɾ ʌv ə haʊs əkɹɔs ðə stʃɹit, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd. "noʊbɑdi ðɛɹ," hi toʊl pɛɹɪn, stɪl ɑn ɪz hɔɹs. "ɪt lʊks laɪk ðeɪ dʒʌst ɡɑɾ ʌp ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə sʌpɝ ən wɔkt əweɪ."

Mat was just coming out of a house across the street, shaking his head. "Nobody there," he told Perrin, still on his horse. "It looks like they just got up in the middle of supper and walked away."

ə ʃaʊt keɪm fɹəm ðə skwɛɹ.

A shout came from the square.

"ðeɪv faʊn sʌmθɪŋ," pɛɹɪn sɛd, dɪɡɪŋ ɪz hilz ɪndə hɪz hɔɹsəz flæŋks. mæt skɹæmbəld ɪndə hɪz sæɾəl ən ɡæləpt æftɝ hɪm.

"They've found something," Perrin said, digging his heels into his horse's flanks. Mat scrambled into his saddle and galloped after him.

ɹænd maʊntəd ɹɛd mɔɹ sloʊli; ðə stæljən ʃaɪɾ əz ɪf filɪŋ ɪz əniz. hi ɡlænst ət ðə haʊsəz əz i ɹoʊd sloʊli təwɔɹd ðə skwɛɹ, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt meɪk hɪmsɛlf lʊk əɾ əm fəɹ lɔŋ. mæt wɛn ɪn wʌn, ən nʌθɪŋ hæpən tə hɪm. hi ɹizɑlv nɑt tə sɛt fʊɾ ɪnsaɪɾ ənʌðɝ haʊs ɪn ðət vɪlədʒ noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt. buɾɪŋ ɹɛd, hi kwɪkən ɪz peɪs.

Rand mounted Red more slowly; the stallion shied as if feeling his unease. He glanced at the houses as he rode slowly toward the square, but he could not make himself look at them for long. Mat went in one, and nothing happened to him. He resolved not to set foot inside another house in that village no matter what. Booting Red, he quickened his pace.

ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz stændɪŋ laɪk stætʃuz ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ə lɑɹdʒ bɪldɪŋ wɪð waɪd dʌbəl dɔɹz. ɹænd dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ɪt kəd bi ən ɪn; ðəɹ wɑz noʊ saɪn, fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ. pɝhæps ə vɪlədʒ miɾɪŋ pleɪs. hi dʒɔɪn ðə saɪlən sɝkəl, ən stɛɹɾ əlɔŋ wɪð ðə ɹɛst.

Everyone was standing like statues in front of a large building with wide double doors. Rand did not think it could be an inn; there was no sign, for one thing. Perhaps a village meeting place. He joined the silent circle, and stared along with the rest.

ðəɹ wɑz ə mæn spɹɛd-iɡəld əkɹɔs ðə dɔɹz wɪð θɪk spaɪks θɹu ɹɪsts ən ʃoʊldɝz. mɔɹ spaɪks hæd bɪn dʒɹɪvən ɪndə hɪz aɪz tə hoʊld ɪz hɛɾ ʌp. dɑɹk, dʒɹaɪd blʌd meɪd fænz daʊn ɪz tʃiks. skʌf mɑɹks ɑn ðə wʊd bɪhaɪn ɪz buts ʃoʊd ðəɾ i hæd bɪn əlaɪv wən ɪt wɑz dʌn. wən ɪt bɪɡæn, ɛniweɪ.

There was a man spread-eagled across the doors with thick spikes through wrists and shoulders. More spikes had been driven into his eyes to hold his head up. Dark, dried blood made fans down his cheeks. Scuff marks on the wood behind his boots showed that he had been alive when it was done. When it began, anyway.

ɹændz bɹɛθ kɑt. nɑɾ ə mæn. ðoʊz blæk kloʊðz, blækɝ ðən blæk, hæd nɛvɝ bɪn wɔɹn baɪ ɛni hjumən. ðə wɪn flæpt ən ɛn ə ðə kloʊk kɑt bɪhaɪn ðə bɑɾi - wɪtʃ ɪt dɪd nɑɾ ɔlweɪz, hi nu tu wɛl; ðə wɪn dɪd nɑɾ ɔlweɪz tʌtʃ ðoʊz kloʊðz - bʌt ðəɹ hæd nɛvɝ bɪn ɛni aɪz ɪn ðət peɪl, blʌdləs feɪs.

Rand's breath caught. Not a man. Those black clothes, blacker than black, had never been worn by any human. The wind flapped an end of the cloak caught behind the body - which it did not always, he knew too well; the wind did not always touch those clothes - but there had never been any eyes in that pale, bloodless face.

"mɹdʒɹɑl," hi bɹiðd, ən ɪt wɑz əz ɪf ɪz spikɪŋ ɹilist ɔl ði ʌðɝz. ðeɪ bɪɡæn tə muv əɡɛn, ən bɹið.

"Myrddraal," he breathed, and it was as if his speaking released all the others. They began to move again, and breathe.

"hu," mæt bɪɡæn, ən hæd tə stɑp tə swɑloʊ. "hu kəd də ðɪs tə ə feɪd?" hɪz vɔɪs skwikt ət ði ɛnd.

"Who," Mat began, and had to stop to swallow. "Who could do this to a Fade?" His voice squeaked at the end.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd. "aɪ də nɑt noʊ." hi lʊkt ɝaʊnd, ɪɡzæmɪnɪŋ feɪsəz, əɹ pɝhæps kaʊntɪŋ tə bi ʃʊɹ ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz ðɛɹ. "æn aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk wɪl lɝn ɛniθɪŋ hɪɹ. wi ɹaɪd. maʊnt! hʊɹɪn, faɪn ðə tʃɹeɪl aʊɾ ə ðɪs pleɪs."

"I don't know," Ingtar said. "I do not know." He looked around, examining faces, or perhaps counting to be sure everyone was there. "And I do not think we will learn anything here. We ride. Mount! Hurin, find the trail out of this place."

"jɛs, maɪ lɔɹd. jɛs. wɪð plɛʒɝ. ðət weɪ, maɪ lɔɹd. ðəɹ stɪl hɛɾɪŋ saʊθ."

"Yes, my Lord. Yes. With pleasure. That way, my Lord. They're still heading south."

ðeɪ ɹoʊɾ əweɪ livɪŋ ðə dɛd mɹdʒɹɑl wɛɹ ɪt hʌŋ, ðə wɪn stɝɪŋ ɪts blæk kloʊk. hʊɹɪn wɑz fɝs bɪɑn ðə wɔl, nɑt weɪɾɪŋ ɑn ɪŋtʃɹ fəɹ ə tʃeɪnʒ, bʌt ɹænd keɪm kloʊs bɪhaɪn hɪm.

They rode away leaving the dead Myrddraal where it hung, the wind stirring its black cloak. Hurin was first beyond the wall, not waiting on Ingtar for a change, but Rand came close behind him.


tʃæptɝ ɪlɛvən


CHAPTER 11

ɡlɪmɝz ə ðə pæɾɝn


Glimmers of the Pattern

fəɹ wʌns, ɪŋtʃɹ kɔld ə hɔl tə ðə deɪz mɑɹtʃ wɪð ðə sʌn stɪl ɡoʊldən əbʌv ðə hɝaɪzən. ðə tʌfənd ʃaɪnɝənz wɝ filɪŋ ði ɪfɛks ʌv wʌt ðeɪ hæd sin ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ. ɪŋtʃɹ hæd nɑt stɑp soʊ ɝli bɪfɔɹ, ən ðə kæmpsaɪɾ i tʃoʊz hæd ðə lʊk ʌv ə pleɪs ðət kəd bi dɪfɛndəd. ɪt wɑz ə dip hɑloʊ, ɔlmoʊst ɹaʊnd, ən bɪɡ ɪnʌf tə hoʊld ɔl ðə mɛn ən hɔɹsəz kʌmfɝɾəbli. ə spɑɹs θɪkɪɾ ə skɹʌb oʊk ən lɛðɝlif kʌvɝd ði aʊɾɝ sloʊps. ðə ɹɪm ɪtsɛlf stʊd mɔɹ ðən haɪ ɪnʌf tə haɪɾ ɛniwʌn ɪn ðə kæmpsaɪɾ ivən wɪθaʊt ðə tʃɹiz. ðə haɪt nɪɹli pæs fəɹ ə hɪl, ɪn ðət kʌntʃɹi.

For once, Ingtar called a halt to the day's march with the sun still golden above the horizon. The toughened Shienarans were feeling the effects of what they had seen in the village. Ingtar had not stopped so early before, and the campsite he chose had the look of a place that could be defended. It was a deep hollow, almost round, and big enough to hold all the men and horses comfortably. A sparse thicket of scrub oak and leatherleaf covered the outer slopes. The rim itself stood more than high enough to hide anyone in the campsite even without the trees. The height nearly passed for a hill, in that country.

"ɔl aɪm blʌɾi seɪɪŋ," hi hɝɾ ənoʊ tɛl ɹeɪɡən əz ðeɪ dɪsmaʊntɪd, "ɪz ðəɾ aɪ blʌɾi sɔ hɝ, bɝn ju. dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ wi faʊn ðə ɡoʊt-kɪsɪŋ hæfmən. ðə seɪm fleɪmɪŋ wʊmən əz ət ðə fleɪmɪŋ fɛɹi. ʃi wɑz ðɛɹ, ən ðən ʃi blʌɾi wɑznt. jə seɪ wʌt jə blʌɾi wɑn tə, bʌt jə wɑtʃ haʊ jə fleɪmɪŋ seɪ ɪt, əɹ əl blʌɾi skɪn jə maɪsɛlf, ən bɝn ðə ɡoʊt-kɪsɪŋ haɪd, jə ʃip-ɡʌɾɪd mɪlk-dʒɹɪŋkɝ."

"All I'm bloody saying," he heard Uno tell Ragan as they dismounted, "is that I bloody saw her, burn you. Just before we found the goat-kissing Halfman. The same flaming woman as at the flaming ferry. She was there, and then she bloody wasn't. You say what you bloody want to, but you watch how you flaming say it, or I'll bloody skin you myself, and burn the goat-kissing hide, you sheep-gutted milk-drinker."

ɹænd pɔzd wɪð wʌn fʊɾ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn ən ði ʌðɝ stɪl ɪn ðə stɝəp. ðə seɪm wʊmən? bʌt ðəɹ wɑzn ɛni wʊmən ət ðə fɛɹi, dʒʌst səm kɝɾənz bloʊɪŋ ɪn ðə wɪnd. ən ʃi kʊdn əv ɡɑɾən tə ðət vɪlədʒ əhɛɾ ʌv əs ɪf ðəɹ hæd bɪn. ðə vɪlədʒ. . . .

Rand paused with one foot on the ground and the other still in the stirrup. The same woman? But there wasn't any woman at the ferry, just some curtains blowing in the wind. And she couldn't have gotten to that village ahead of us if there had been. The village. . . .

hi ʃaɪɾ əweɪ fɹəm ðə θɔt. ivən mɔɹ ðən ðə feɪd neɪl tə ðə dɔɹ, hi wɑntəd tə fɝɡɛt ðət ɹum, ən ðə flaɪz, ən ðə pipəl u wɝ ðəɹ ən nɑt ðɛɹ. ðə hæfmən hæd bɪn ɹil - ɛvɹibɑɾi hæd sin ðət - bʌt ðə ɹum. . . . meɪbi aɪm faɪnəli ɡoʊɪŋ mæd. hi wɪʃt mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz ðəɹ tə tɔk tə. wɪʃɪŋ fəɹ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. jə ɑɹ ə ful. jəɹ wɛl aʊɾ ə ðæt, naʊ steɪ aʊt. bʌɾ æm aɪ aʊt? wʌt hæpən ðɛɹ?

He shied away from the thought. Even more than the Fade nailed to the door, he wanted to forget that room, and the flies, and the people who were there and not there. The Halfman had been real - everybody had seen that - but the room. . . . Maybe I'm finally going mad. He wished Moiraine was there to talk to. Wishing for an Aes Sedai. You are a fool. You're well out of that, now stay out. But am I out? What happened there?

"pækhɔɹsɪz ən səplaɪz ɪn ðə mɪɾəl," ɪŋtʃɹ kəmændəɾ əz ðə lænsɝz wɛn əbaʊt sɛɾɪŋ ʌp kæmp. "ɹʌb ðə hɔɹsəz daʊn, ðən sæɾəl əm əɡɛn ɪn keɪs wi mʌs muv kwɪkli. ɛvɹi mæn slips baɪ hɪz maʊnt, ən ðɛɹəl bi noʊ faɪɝz tənaɪt. wɑtʃ tʃeɪnʒəz ɛvɹi tu aʊɝz. ənoʊ, aɪ wɑn skaʊts aʊt, əz fɑɹ əz ðeɪ kən ɹaɪɾ ən ɹɪtɝn bɪfɔɹ dɑɹk. aɪ wɑnə noʊ wʌɾ ɪz aʊt ðɛɹ."

"packhorses and supplies in the middle," Ingtar commanded as the lancers went about setting up camp. "Rub the horses down, then saddle them again in case we must move quickly. Every man sleeps by his mount, and there'll be no fires tonight. Watch changes every two hours. Uno, I want scouts out, as far as they can ride and return before dark. I want to know what is out there."

hiz filɪŋ ɪt, ɹænd θɔt. ɪɾ ɪzən dʒʌst səm dɑɹkfɹɛnz ən ə fju tʃɹɑləks ən meɪbi ə feɪɾ ɛnimɔɹ. dʒʌst səm dɑɹkfɹɛnz ən ə fju tʃɹɑləks, ən meɪbi ə feɪd! ivən ə fju deɪz bɪfɔɹ ðəɹ wəd nɑɾ əv bɪn ɛni "dʒʌst" əbaʊɾ ɪt. ivən ɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz, ivən wɪð ðə blaɪt lɛs ðən ə deɪz ɹaɪd, dɑɹkfɹɛnz ən tʃɹɑləks ən mɹdʒɹɑl hæd bɪn bæɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ ə naɪtmɛɹ, ðɛn. bɪfɔɹ i hæd sin ə mɹdʒɹɑl neɪl tə ə dɔɹ. wʌɾ ɪn ðə laɪt cʊɾə dʌn ðæt? wʌt nɑɾ ɪn ðə laɪt? bɪfɔɹ i hæd wɔkt ɪndə ə ɹum wɛɹ ə fæmli hæd hæd ðɛɹ sʌpɝ ən ðɛɹ læftɝ kʌɾ ɔf. aɪ mʌst əv ɪmædʒən ɪt. aɪ mʌs hæv. ivən ɪn ɪz oʊn hɛɾ i dɪd nɑt saʊn vɛɹi kənvɪnsɪŋ. hi hæd nɑɾ ɪmædʒən ðə wɪn ɑn ðə taʊɝ tɑp, əɹ ði æmɪɝlɪn seɪɪŋ -  "ɹænd?" hi dʒʌmpt əz ɪŋtʃɹ spoʊk əɾ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. "ɑɹ jə gɑnə steɪ ɔl naɪt wɪð wʌn fʊɾ ɪn ðə stɝəp?"

He's feeling it, Rand thought. It isn't just some Darkfriends and a few Trollocs and maybe a Fade anymore. Just some Darkfriends and a few Trollocs, and maybe a Fade! Even a few days before there would not have been any "just" about it. Even in the Borderlands, even with the Blight less than a day's ride, Darkfriends and Trollocs and Myrddraal had been bad enough for a nightmare, then. Before he had seen a Myrddraal nailed to a door. What in the Light could have done that? What not in the Light? Before he had walked into a room where a family had had their supper and their laughter cut off. I must have imagined it. I must have. Even in his own head he did not sound very convincing. He had not imagined the wind on the tower top, or the Amyrlin saying -  "Rand?" He jumped as Ingtar spoke at his shoulder. "Are you going to stay all night with one foot in the stirrup?"

ɹænd pʊɾ ɪz ʌðɝ fʊɾ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. "ɪŋtʃɹ, wʌt hæpən bæk ət ðət vɪlədʒ?"

Rand put his other foot on the ground. "Ingtar, what happened back at that village?"

"tʃɹɑləks tʊk ðɛm. ðə seɪm əz ðə pipəl ət ðə fɛɹi. ðəɾ ɪz wʌt hæpənd. ðə feɪd. . . ." ɪŋtʃɹ ʃɹʌɡd ən stɛɹd daʊn əɾ ə flæt, kænvəs-ɹæp bʌndəl, lɑɹdʒ ən skwɛɹ, ɪn ɪz ɑɹmz; hi stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪɾ əz ɪf i sɔ hɪɾən sikɹəts i wəd ɹæðɝ nɑt noʊ. "ðə tʃɹɑləks tʊk əm fəɹ fud. ðeɪ də ɪɾ ɪn vɪlədʒəz ən fɑɹmz nɪɹ ðə blaɪt, tu, səmtaɪmz, ɪf ə ɹeɪd ɡɛts pæs ðə bɔɹɾɝ taʊɝz ɪn ðə naɪt. səmtaɪmz wi ɡɛt ðə pipəl bæk, ən səmtaɪmz nɑt. səmtaɪmz wi ɡɛɾ əm bæk ən ɔlmoʊst wɪʃ wi hædnt. tʃɹɑləks doʊn ɔlweɪz kɪl bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ stɑɹt bʊtʃɝɪŋ. ən hæfmən laɪk tə hæv ðɛɹ . . . fʌn. ðæts wɝs ðən wʌt ðə tʃɹɑləks du." hɪz vɔɪs wɑz əz stɛɾi əz ɪf i wɝ tɔkɪŋ ʌv ɛvɹi deɪ, ən pɝhæps i wɑz, fəɹ ə ʃaɪnɝən soʊlʒɝ.

"Trollocs took them. The same as the people at the ferry. That is what happened. The Fade. . . ." Ingtar shrugged and stared down at a flat, canvas-wrapped bundle, large and square, in his arms; he stared at it as if he saw hidden secrets he would rather not know. "The Trollocs took them for food. They do it in villages and farms near the Blight, too, sometimes, if a raid gets past the border towers in the night. Sometimes we get the people back, and sometimes not. Sometimes we get them back and almost wish we hadn't. Trollocs don't always kill before they start butchering. And Halfmen like to have their . . . fun. That's worse than what the Trollocs do." His voice was as steady as if he were talking of every day, and perhaps he was, for a Shienaran soldier.

ɹænd tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ tə stɛɾi hɪz stʌmək. "ðə feɪd bæk ðəɹ dɪdn əv ɛni fʌn, ɪŋtʃɹ. wʌt kəd neɪl ə mɹdʒɹɑl tə ə dɔɹ, əlaɪv?"

Rand took a deep breath to steady his stomach. "The Fade back there didn't have any fun, Ingtar. What could nail a Myrddraal to a door, alive?"

ɪŋtʃɹ hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd, ðən pʊʃt ðə bɪɡ bʌndəl ət ɹænd. "hɪɹ. mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ toʊl mi tə ɡɪv jə ðɪs ət ðə fɝs kæmp saʊθ ə ði ɛɹɪnɪn. aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌɾ ɪz ɪn ɪt, bʌt ʃi sɛd jə wəd niɾ ɪt. ʃi sɛd tə tɛl jə tə teɪk kɛɹ ʌv ɪt; jəɹ laɪf meɪ dɪpɛn ɑn ɪt."

Ingtar hesitated, shaking his head, then pushed the big bundle at Rand. "Here. Moiraine Sedai told me to give you this at the first camp south of the Erinin. I don't know what is in it, but she said you would need it. She said to tell you to take care of it; your life may depend on it."

ɹænd tʊk ɪt ɹɪlʌktənli; hɪz skɪn pɹɪkəld ət ðə tʌtʃ ə ðə kænvəs. ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ sɑft ɪnsaɪd. klɔθ, meɪbi. hi hɛld ɪt dʒɪnʒɝli. hi dʌznt wɑnə θɪŋk əbaʊt ðə mɹdʒɹɑl iðɝ. wʌt hæpən ɪn ðət ɹum? hi ɹilaɪz sʌɾənli ðət fəɹ hɪm, ðə feɪd, əɹ ivən ðət ɹum, wɑz pɹɛfɝəbəl tə θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt wʌt mɔɪɹeɪn maɪɾ əv sɛn hɪm.

Rand took it reluctantly; his skin prickled at the touch of the canvas. There was something soft inside. Cloth, maybe. He held it gingerly. He doesn't want to think about the Myrddraal either. What happened in that room? He realized suddenly that for him, the Fade, or even that room, was preferable to thinking about what Moiraine might have sent him.

"aɪ wɑz toʊl tə tɛl jə ət ðə seɪm taɪm ðəɾ ɪf ɛniθɪŋ hæpənz tə mi, ðə lænsɪz wɪl fɑloʊ ju."

"I was told to tell you at the same time that if anything happens to me, the lances will follow you."

"mi!" ɹænd ɡæspt, fɝɡɛɾɪŋ ðə bʌndəl ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls. ɪŋtʃɹ mɛɾ ɪz ɪnkɹɛdʒələs stɛɹ wɪð ə kɑm nɑd. "ðæts kɹeɪzi! aɪv nɛvɝ lɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ bʌɾ ə flɑk ə ʃip, ɪŋtʃɹ. ðeɪ wəd nɑt fɑloʊ mi ɛniweɪ. bɪsaɪdz, mɔɪɹeɪn kæn tɛl jə hu jəɹ sɛkən ɪz. ɪts ənoʊ."

"Me!" Rand gasped, forgetting the bundle and everything else. Ingtar met his incredulous stare with a calm nod. "That's crazy! I've never led anything but a flock of sheep, Ingtar. They would not follow me anyway. Besides, Moiraine can't tell you who your second is. It's Uno."

"ənoʊ ən aɪ wɝ kɔl tə lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ ðə mɔɹnɪŋ wi lɛft. mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ wɑz ðɛɹ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ u toʊl mi. jə ɑɹ sɛkənd, ɹænd."

"Uno and I were called to Lord Agelmar the morning we left. Moiraine Sedai was there, but it was Lord Agelmar who told me. You are second, Rand."

"bʌt waɪ, ɪŋtʃɹ? waɪ?" mɔɪɹeɪnz hænd wɑz bɹaɪɾ ən klɪɹ ɪn ɪt, hɝz ən ði æmɪɝlɪnz, pʊʃɪŋ ɪm əlɔŋ ðə pæθ ðeɪ hæd tʃoʊzən, bʌɾ i hæd tə æsk.

"But why, Ingtar? Why?" Moiraine's hand was bright and clear in it, hers and the Amyrlin's, pushing him along the path they had chosen, but he had to ask.

ðə ʃaɪnɝən lʊkt əz ɪf i dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ɪɾ iðɝ, bʌɾ i wɑz ə soʊlʒɝ, juz tə ɑd kəmænz ɪn ði ɛnləs wɔɹ əlɔŋ ðə blaɪt. "aɪ hɝd ɹumɝz fɹəm ðə wɪmənz əpɑɹtməns ðət jə wɝ ɹɪli eɪ. . . ." hi spɹɛd ɡɔntələɾəd hænz. "noʊ mæɾɝ. aɪ noʊ jə dɪnaɪ ɪt. dʒʌst əz jə dɪnaɪ ðə lʊk ə jəɹ oʊn feɪs. mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ sɛz jəɹ ə ʃɛpɝd, bʌɾ aɪ nɛvɝ sɔ ə ʃɛpɝd wɪð ə hɛɹən-mɑɹk bleɪd. noʊ mæɾɝ. əl nɑt kleɪm aɪ wʊɾə tʃoʊzən jə maɪsɛlf, bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk juv ɪɾ ɪn jə tə də wʌɾ ɪz niɾəd. jəl də jəɹ duɾi, ɪf ɪt kʌmz tə ɪt."

The Shienaran looked as if he did not understand it either, but he was a soldier, used to odd commands in the endless war along the Blight. "I heard rumors from the women's apartments that you were really a. . . ." He spread gauntleted hands. "No matter. I know you deny it. Just as you deny the look of your own face. Moiraine Sedai says you're a shepherd, but I never saw a shepherd with a heron-mark blade. No matter. I'll not claim I would have chosen you myself, but I think you have it in you to do what is needed. You will do your duty, if it comes to it."

ɹænd wɑntəd tə seɪ ɪt wɑz noʊ duɾi ʌv hɪz, bʌɾ ɪnstɛɾ i sɛd, "ənoʊ noʊz əbaʊt ðɪs. hu ɛls, ɪŋtʃɹ?"

Rand wanted to say it was no duty of his, but instead he said, "Uno knows about this. Who else, Ingtar?"

"ɔl ðə lænsɪz. wən wi ʃaɪnɝənz ɹaɪd, ɛvɹi mæn noʊz u ɪz nɛkst ɪn laɪn ɪf ðə mæn ɪn kəmæn fɔlz. ə tʃeɪn ənbɹoʊkən ɹaɪt daʊn tə ðə læs mæn lɛft, ivən ɪf hiz nʌθɪŋ bʌɾ ə hɔɹshoʊldɝ. ðət weɪ, jə si, ivən ɪf hiz ðə læs mæn, hiz nɑt dʒʌst ə stʃɹæɡəlɝ ɹʌnɪŋ ən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə steɪ əlaɪv. hiz ðə kəmænd, ən duɾi kɔlz ɪm tə də wʌt mʌs bi dʌn. ɪf aɪ ɡoʊ tə ðə læst ɛmbɹeɪs ə ðə mʌðɝ, ðə duɾi ɪz jʊɹz. jəl faɪn ðə hɔɹn, ən jəl teɪk ɪt wɛɹ ɪt bɪlɔŋz. jə wɪl." ðəɹ wɑz ə pəkjuljɝ ɛmfəsəs ɪn ɪŋtʃɹz læst wɝdz.

"All the lances. When we Shienarans ride, every man knows who is next in line if the man in command falls. A chain unbroken right down to the last man left, even if he's nothing but a horseholder. That way, you see, even if he is the last man, he is not just a straggler running and trying to stay alive. He has the command, and duty calls him to do what must be done. If I go to the last embrace of the mother, the duty is yours. You will find the Horn, and you will take it where it belongs. You will." There was a peculiar emphasis in Ingtar's last words.

ðə bʌndəl ɪn ɹændz ɑɹmz sim tə weɪ tɛn stoʊn. laɪt, ʃi kəd bi ə hʌnʒɹəd liɡz ɔf, ən ʃi stɪl ɹitʃəz aʊɾ ən tʌɡz ðə liʃ. ðɪs weɪ, ɹænd. ðət weɪ. jəɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ɹænd. "aɪ doʊnt wɑn ðə duɾi, ɪŋtʃɹ. əl nɑt teɪk ɪt. laɪt, aɪm dʒʌst ə ʃɛpɝd! waɪ woʊn ɛnibəɾi bɪliv ðæt?"
