The bundle in Rand's arms seemed to weigh ten stone. Light, she could be a hundred leagues off, and she still reaches out and tugs the leash. This way, Rand. That way. You're the Dragon Reborn, Rand. "I don't want the duty, Ingtar. I will not take it. Light, I'm just a shepherd! Why won't anybody believe that?"

"ju wɪl də jəɹ duɾi, ɹænd. wən ðə mæn ət ðə tɑp ə ðə tʃeɪn feɪlz, ɛvɹiθɪŋ bɪloʊ hɪm fɔlz əpɑɹt. tu mʌtʃ ɪz fɔlɪŋ əpɑɹt. tu mʌtʃ ɔlɹɛɾi. pis feɪvɝ jəɹ sɔɹd, ɹænd ælθɹ."

"You will do your duty, Rand. When the man at the top of the chain fails, everything below him falls apart. Too much is falling apart. Too much already. Peace favor your sword, Rand al'Thor."

"ɪŋtʃɹ, aɪ - " bʌɾ ɪŋtʃɹ wɑz wɔkɪŋ əweɪ, kɔlɪŋ tə si ɪf ənoʊ hæd ðə skaʊts aʊt jɛt.

"Ingtar, I - " But Ingtar was walking away, calling to see if Uno had the scouts out yet.

ɹænd stɛɹɾ ət ðə bʌndəl ɪn ɪz ɑɹmz ən lɪkt ɪz lɪps. hi wɑz əfɹeɪɾ i nu wʌt wɑz ɪn ɪt. hi wɑntəd tə lʊk, jɛɾ i wɑntəd tə θɹoʊ ɪɾ ɪn ə faɪɝ wɪθaʊɾ oʊpənɪŋ ɪt; hi θɔɾ i maɪt, ɪf i kəd bi ʃʊɹ ɪt wəd bɝn wɪθaʊɾ ɛniwʌn siɪŋ wʌt wɑz ɪnsaɪd, ɪf i kəd bi ʃʊɹ wʌt wɑz ɪnsaɪd wəd bɝn əɾ ɔl. bʌɾ i kəd nɑt lʊk ðɛɹ, wɛɹ ʌðɝ aɪz ðən ɪz maɪt si.

Rand stared at the bundle in his arms and licked his lips. He was afraid he knew what was in it. He wanted to look, yet he wanted to throw it in a fire without opening it; he thought he might, if he could be sure it would burn without anyone seeing what was inside, if he could be sure what was inside would burn at all. But he could not look there, where other eyes than his might see.

hi ɡlænst ɝaʊn ðə kæmp. ðə ʃaɪnɝənz wɝ ənloʊɾɪŋ ðə pæk ænəməlz, səm ɔlɹɛɾi hændɪŋ aʊɾ ə koʊl sʌpɝ ə dʒɹaɪd miɾ ən flætbɹɛd. mæt ən pɛɹɪn tɛndəd ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz, ən lɔɪəl sæɾ ɑn ə stoʊn ɹiɾɪŋ ə bʊk, wɪð ɪz lɔŋ-stɛm paɪp klɛntʃt bɪtwin ɪz tiθ ən ə wɪsp ə smoʊk kɝlɪŋ əbʌv ɪz hɛd. ɡɹɪpɪŋ ðə bʌndəl əz ɪf əfɹeɪɾ i maɪt dʒɹɑp ɪt, ɹænd snikt ɪndə ðə tʃɹiz.

He glanced around the camp. The Shienarans were unloading the pack animals, some already handing out a cold supper of dried meat and flatbread. Mat and Perrin tended their horses, and Loial sat on a stone reading a book, with his long-stemmed pipe clenched between his teeth and a wisp of smoke curling above his head. Gripping the bundle as if afraid he might drop it, Rand sneaked into the trees.

hi nɛlt ɪn ə smɔl klɪɹɪŋ ʃɛltɝd baɪ θɪk-foʊlidʒ bɹæntʃəz ən sɛt ðə bʌndəl ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. fəɹ ə taɪm i dʒʌst stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪt. ʃi wʊdn hæv. ʃi kʊdnt. ə smɔl vɔɪs ænsɝd, oʊ, jɛs, ʃi kʊd. ʃi kəɾ ən wʊd. faɪnəli hi sɛɾ əbaʊɾ əntiɪŋ ðə smɔl nɑts ɪn ðə kɔɹdz ðət baʊn ɪt. nit nɑts, taɪd wɪð ə pɹisɪʒən ðət spoʊk laʊdli ʌv mɔɪɹeɪnz oʊn hænd; noʊ sɝvən hæd dʌn ðɪs fəɹ hɝ. ʃi wəd nɑɾ əv dɛɹd lɛɾ ɛni sɝvən si.

He knelt in a small clearing sheltered by thick-foliaged branches and set the bundle on the ground. For a time he just stared at it. She wouldn't have. She couldn't. A small voice answered, Oh, yes, she could. She could and would. Finally he set about untying the small knots in the cords that bound it. Neat knots, tied with a precision that spoke loudly of Moiraine's own hand; no servant had done this for her. She would not have dared let any servant see.

wən i hæd ðə læs kɔɹɾ ənfæsənd, hi oʊpən aʊt wʌt wɑz foʊldəɾ ɪnsaɪd wɪð hænz ðət fɛl nʌm, ðən stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪt, hɪz maʊθ fʊl ə dʌst. ɪt wɑz ɔl ʌv wʌn pis, niðɝ woʊvən, nɔɹ daɪd, nɔɹ peɪntəd. ə bænɝ, waɪɾ əz snoʊ, bɪɡ ɪnʌf tə bi sin ðə lɛŋθ ʌv ə fild ə bæɾəl. ən əkɹɔs ɪt mɑɹtʃt ə ɹɪpəlɪŋ fɪɡjɝ laɪk ə sɝpən skeɪld ɪn ɡoʊld ən kɹɪmzən, bʌɾ ə sɝpənt wɪð fɔɹ skeɪld lɛɡz, itʃ tɪpt wɪð faɪv ɡoʊldən klɔz, ə sɝpənt wɪð aɪz laɪk ðə sʌn ən ə ɡoʊldən laɪənz meɪn. hi hæd sin ɪt wʌns bɪfɔɹ, ən mɔɪɹeɪn hæd toʊld ɪm wʌɾ ɪt wɑz. ðə bænɝ ə luz θɝɪn tɛləmən, luz θɝɪn kɪnsleɪɝ, ɪn ðə wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ. ðə bænɝ ə ðə dʒɹæɡən.

When he had the last cord unfastened, he opened out what was folded inside with hands that felt numb, then stared at it, his mouth full of dust. It was all of one piece, neither woven, nor dyed, nor painted. A banner, white as snow, big enough to be seen the length of a field of battle. And across it marched a rippling figure like a serpent scaled in gold and crimson, but a serpent with four scaled legs, each tipped with five golden claws, a serpent with eyes like the sun and a golden lion's mane. He had seen it once before, and Moiraine had told him what it was. The banner of Lews Therin Telamon, Lews Therin Kinslayer, in the War of the Shadow. The banner of the Dragon.

"lʊk ət ðæt! lʊk wʌt hiz ɡɑt, naʊ!" mæt bɝst ɪndə ðə klɪɹɪŋ. pɛɹɪn keɪm æftɝ ɪm mɔɹ sloʊli. "fɝs fænsi koʊts," mæt snɑɹəld, "ænd naʊ ə bænɝ! wɪl hɪɹ noʊ ɛn ə lɔɹɾɪŋ ɪt naʊ, wɪð - " mæt ɡɑt kloʊs ɪnʌf tə si ðə bænɝ klɪɹli, ən ɪz dʒɔ dʒɹɑpt. "laɪt!" hi stʌmbəl bæk ə stɛp. "bɝn mi!" hi hæd bɪn ðɛɹ, tu, wən mɔɪɹeɪn neɪm ðə bænɝ. soʊ hæd pɛɹɪn.

"Look at that! Look what he's got, now!" Mat burst into the clearing. Perrin came after him more slowly. "First fancy coats," Mat snarled, "and now a banner! We'll hear no end of lording it now, with - " Mat got close enough to see the banner clearly, and his jaw dropped. "Light!" He stumbled back a step. "Burn me!" He had been there, too, when Moiraine named the banner. So had Perrin.

æŋɡɝ bɔɪld ʌp ɪn ɹænd, æŋɡɝ ət mɔɪɹeɪn ən ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, pʊʃɪŋ hɪm, pʊlɪŋ hɪm. hi snætʃt ʌp ðə bænɝ ɪn boʊθ hænz ən ʃʊk ɪɾ ət mæt, wɝdz bɔɪlɪŋ aʊɾ ʌnkəntʃɹoʊləbli. "ðæts ɹaɪt! ðə dʒɹæɡənz bænɝ!" mæt tʊk ənʌðɝ stɛp bæk. "mɔɪɹeɪn wɑns mi tə bi ə pʌpəɾ ɑn tɑɹ vəlɑn stʃɹɪŋz, ə fɔls dʒɹæɡən fəɹ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ʃiz gɑnə pʊʃ ɪt daʊn maɪ θɹoʊt wʌtɛvɝ aɪ wɑnt. bʌt - aɪ - wɪl - nɑt - bi - juzd!"

Anger boiled up in Rand, anger at Moiraine and the Amyrlin Seat, pushing him, pulling him. He snatched up the banner in both hands and shook it at Mat, words boiling out uncontrollably. "That's right! The Dragon's banner!" Mat took another step back. "Moiraine wants me to be a puppet on Tar Valon strings, a false Dragon for the Aes Sedai. She's going to push it down my throat whatever I want. But - I - will - not - be - used!"

mæt hæd bækt ʌp əɡɛnst ə tʃɹi tʃɹʌŋk. "ə fɔls dʒɹæɡən?" hi swɑloʊd. "ju? ðət . . . ðæts kɹeɪzi."

Mat had backed up against a tree trunk. "A false Dragon?" He swallowed. "You? That . . . that's crazy."

pɛɹɪn hæd nɑt ɹitʃɹiɾəd. hi skwɑɾɪd daʊn wɪð ɪz θɪk ɑɹmz ɑn ɪz niz ən stʌɾid ɹænd wɪð ðoʊz bɹaɪt ɡoʊldən aɪz. ɪn ði ivnɪŋ ʃædoʊz ðeɪ sim tə ʃaɪn. "ɪf ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑn jə fəɹ ə fɔls dʒɹæɡən. . . ." hi pɔzd, fɹaʊnɪŋ, θɪŋkɪŋ θɪŋz θɹu. faɪnəli, hi sɛd kwaɪətli, "ɹænd, kən jə tʃænəl?" mæt ɡeɪv ə stʃɹæŋɡəld ɡæsp.

Perrin had not retreated. He squatted down with his thick arms on his knees and studied Rand with those bright golden eyes. In the evening shadows they seemed to shine. "If the Aes Sedai want you for a false Dragon. . . ." He paused, frowning, thinking things through. Finally, he said quietly, "Rand, can you channel?" Mat gave a strangled gasp.

ɹænd lɛt ðə bænɝ dʒɹɑp; hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd oʊnli ə moʊmən bɪfɔɹ nɑɾɪŋ wɛɹəli. "aɪ dɪd nɑɾ æsk fəɹ ɪt. aɪ doʊnt wɑn ɪt. bʌt. . . . bʌɾ aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk aɪ noʊ haʊ tə stɑp ɪt." ðə ɹum wɪð ðə flaɪz keɪm bæk ənbɪddən tə hɪz maɪnd. "aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðəl lemi stɑp."

Rand let the banner drop; he hesitated only a moment before nodding wearily. "I did not ask for it. I don't want it. But. . . . But I do not think I know how to stop it." The room with the flies came back unbidden to his mind. "I don't think they'll let me stop."

"bɝn mi!" mæt bɹiðd. "blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz! ðəl kɪl ʌs, jə noʊ. ɔl ʌv ʌs. pɛɹɪn ən mi əz wɛl əz ju. ɪf ɪŋtʃɹ ən ði ʌðɝz faɪn aʊt, ðəl kʌɾ əɹ blʌɾi θɹoʊts fəɹ dɑɹkfɹɛnz. laɪt, ðəl pɹɑbli θɪŋk wi wɝ pɑɹɾ ə stilɪŋ ðə hɔɹn, ən kɪlɪŋ ðoʊz pipəl ɪn fæl dæɹə."

"Burn me!" Mat breathed. "Blood and bloody ashes! They'll kill us, you know. All of us. Perrin and me as well as you. If Ingtar and the others find out, they will cut our bloody throats for Darkfriends. Light, they'll probably think we were part of stealing the Horn, and killing those people in Fal Dara."

"ʃʌɾ ʌp, mæt," pɛɹɪn sɛd kɑmli.

"Shut up, Mat," Perrin said calmly.

"doʊn tɛl mi tə ʃʌɾ ʌp. ɪf ɪŋtʃɹ dʌzn kɪl ʌs, ɹænd wɪl ɡoʊ mæɾ ən də ɪt fəɹ hɪm. bɝn mi! bɝn mi!" mæt slɪd daʊn ðə tʃɹi tə sɪɾ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. "waɪ dɪdn ðeɪ dʒɛntəl ju? ɪf ði ɛɛs sədaɪ noʊ, waɪ dɪdn ðeɪ dʒɛntəl ju? aɪ nɛvɝ hɝɾ ə ðɛm lɛɾɪŋ ə mæn u kən wil ðə paʊɝ dʒʌst wɔk əweɪ."

"Don't tell me to shut up. If Ingtar doesn't kill us, Rand will go mad and do it for him. Burn me! Burn me!" Mat slid down the tree to sit on the ground. "Why didn't they gentle you? If the Aes Sedai know, why didn't they gentle you? I never heard of them letting a man who can wield the Power just walk away."

"ðeɪ doʊn ɔl noʊ," ɹænd saɪd. "ði æmɪɝlɪn - "

"They don't all know," Rand sighed. "The Amyrlin - "

"ði æmɪɝlɪn sit! ʃi noʊz? laɪt, noʊ wʌndɝ ʃi lʊkt ət mi soʊ stʃɹeɪnʒ."

"The Amyrlin Seat! She knows? Light, no wonder she looked at me so strange."

" - ən mɔɪɹeɪn toʊl mi ɪm ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ən ðən ðeɪ sɛɾ aɪ kəd ɡoʊ wɛɹɛvɝ aɪ wɑntəd. doʊn jə si, mæt? ðeɪ ɑɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə juz mi."

" - and Moiraine told me I'm the Dragon Reborn, and then they said I could go wherever I wanted. Don't you see, Mat? They are trying to use me."

"dʌzn tʃeɪnʒ jə biɪŋ eɪbəl tə tʃænəl," mæt mʌɾɝd. "ɪf aɪ wɝ ju, aɪd bi hæfweɪ tə ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən baɪ naʊ. ən aɪ wəd nɑt stɑp əntɪl aɪ faʊn sʌmpleɪs wɛɹ ðəɹ wɝ noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən nɛvɝ laɪkli tə bi ɛni. ən noʊ pipəl. aɪ min . . . wɛl. . . ."

"Doesn't change you being able to channel," Mat muttered. "If I were you, I'd be halfway to the Aryth Ocean by now. And I would not stop until I found someplace where there were no Aes Sedai, and never likely to be any. And no people. I mean . . . well. . . ."

"ʃʌɾ ʌp, mæt," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "waɪ ɑɹ jə hɪɹ, ɹænd? ðə lɔŋɡɝ jə steɪ ɝaʊn pipəl, ðə mɔɹ laɪkli ɪts sʌmbɑɾi wɪl faɪn aʊɾ ən sɛn fəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɛɛs sədaɪ hu woʊn tɛl jə tə ɡoʊ ɑn əbaʊt jəɹ bɪznəs." hi pɔzd, skɹætʃɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ oʊvɝ ðæt. "æn mæts ɹaɪɾ əbaʊɾ ɪŋtʃɹ. aɪ doʊn daʊɾ i wəd neɪm jə dɑɹkfɹɛn ən kɪl ju. kɪl ɔl ʌv ʌs, meɪbi. hi simz tə laɪk ju, bʌt hid stɪl də ɪt, aɪ θɪŋk. ə fɔls dʒɹæɡən? soʊ wəd ði ʌðɝz. mæsimə wʊdnt nid ðət mʌtʃ ɪkskjus, fəɹ ju. soʊ waɪ ɑɹən jə ɡɔn?"

"Shut up, Mat," Perrin said. "Why are you here, Rand? The longer you stay around people, the more likely it is somebody will find out and send for Aes Sedai. Aes Sedai who won't tell you to go on about your business." He paused, scratching his head over that. "And Mat's right about Ingtar. I don't doubt he would name you Darkfriend and kill you. Kill all of us, maybe. He seems to like you, but he'd still do it, I think. A false Dragon? So would the others. Masema wouldn't need that much excuse, for you. So why aren't you gone?"

ɹænd ʃɹʌɡd. "aɪ wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ, bʌt fɝs ði æmɪɝlɪn keɪm, ən ðən ðə hɔɹn wɑz stoʊlən, ən ðə dæɡɝ, ən mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd mæt wɑz daɪɪŋ, ænd. . . . laɪt, aɪ θɔɾ aɪ kəd steɪ wɪð jə əntɪl wi faʊn ðə dæɡɝ, ət list; aɪ θɔɾ aɪ kəd hɛlp wɪð ðæt. meɪbi aɪ wɑz ɹɔŋ."

Rand shrugged. "I was going, but first the Amyrlin came, and then the Horn was stolen, and the dagger, and Moiraine said Mat was dying, and. . . . Light, I thought I could stay with you until we found the dagger, at least; I thought I could help with that. Maybe I was wrong."

"ju keɪm kəz ə ðə dæɡɝ?" mæt sɛd kwaɪətli. hi ɹʌbd ɪz noʊz ən ɡɹɪməst. "aɪ nɛvɝ θɔɾ ə ðæt. aɪ nɛvɝ θɔt jə wɑntəd tə. . . . ɑə! ɑɹ jə filɪŋ ɔl ɹaɪt? aɪ min, jə ɑɹənt ɡoʊɪŋ mæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi, ɑɹ ju?"

"You came because of the dagger?" Mat said quietly. He rubbed his nose and grimaced. "I never thought of that. I never thought you wanted to. . . . Aaaah! Are you feeling all right? I mean, you aren't going mad already, are you?"

ɹænd dʌɡ ə pɛbəl aʊɾ ə ðə ɡɹaʊn ən θɹu ɪɾ ət hɪm.

Rand dug a pebble out of the ground and threw it at him.

"aʊtʃ!" mæt ɹʌbd ɪz ɑɹm. "aɪ wɑz dʒʌst æskɪŋ. aɪ min, ɔl ðoʊz fænsi kloʊðz, ən ɔl ðət tɔk əbaʊt biɪŋ ə lɔɹd. wɛl, ðəɾ ɪzən ɪɡzækli ɹaɪɾ ɪn ðə hɛd."

"Ouch!" Mat rubbed his arm. "I was just asking. I mean, all those fancy clothes, and all that talk about being a lord. Well, that isn't exactly right in the head."

"aɪ wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡɛt ɹɪɾ ə ju, ful! aɪ wɑz əfɹeɪɾ aɪd ɡoʊ mæɾ ən hɝt ju." hɪz aɪz dʒɹɑp tə ðə bænɝ, ən ɪz vɔɪs loʊɝd. "aɪ wɪl, ɪvɛntʃəwəli, ɪf aɪ doʊn stɑp ɪt. laɪt, aɪ doʊnt noʊ haʊ tə stɑp ɪt."

"I was trying to get rid of you, fool! I was afraid I'd go mad and hurt you." His eyes dropped to the banner, and his voice lowered. "I will, eventually, if I don't stop it. Light, I don't know how to stop it."

"ðæɾ ɪz wʌɾ aɪm əfɹeɪɾ ʌv," mæt sɛd, stændɪŋ. "noʊ əfɛns, ɹænd, bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk əl dʒʌst slip əz fɑɹ əweɪ fɹəm jə əz aɪ kæn, ɪf jə doʊn maɪnd. ðæts ɪf jə ɑɹ steɪɪŋ. aɪ hɝɾ əbaʊɾ ə fɛloʊ hu kəd tʃænəl, wʌns. ə mɝtʃəns ɡɑɹd toʊl mi. bɪfɔɹ ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ faʊn hɪm, hi woʊk wʌn mɔɹnɪŋ, ən ɪz hoʊl vɪlədʒ wɑz smæʃt flæt. ɔl ðə haʊsəz, ɔl ðə pipəl, ɛvɹiθɪŋ bʌt ðə bɛɾ i wɑz slipɪŋ ɪn, laɪk ə maʊntən hæd ɹoʊld oʊvɝ ðɛm."

"That is what I'm afraid of," Mat said, standing. "No offense, Rand, but I think I will just sleep as far away from you as I can, if you don't mind. That's if you are staying. I heard about a fellow who could channel, once. A merchant's guard told me. Before the Red Ajah found him, he woke one morning, and his whole village was smashed flat. All the houses, all the people, everything but the bed he was sleeping in, like a mountain had rolled over them."

pɛɹɪn sɛd, "ɪn ðət keɪs, mæt, jə ʃəd slip tʃik baɪ dʒaʊl wɪð hɪm."

Perrin said, "In that case, Mat, you should sleep cheek by jowl with him."

"aɪ meɪ bi ə ful, bʌɾ aɪ ɪntɛn tə bi ə laɪv ful." mæt hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, lʊkɪŋ saɪdweɪz ət ɹænd. "lʊk, aɪ noʊ jə keɪm əlɔŋ tə hɛlp mi, ən aɪm ɡɹeɪtfəl. aɪ ɹɪli æm. bʌt jə dʒʌst ɑɹ nɑt ðə seɪm ɛnimɔɹ. jə ʌndɝstæn ðæt, doʊn ju?" hi weɪɾəd əz ɪf i ɪkspɛktəɾ ən ænsɝ. nʌn keɪm. faɪnəli hi vænɪʃt ɪndə ðə tʃɹiz, bæk təwɔɹd ðə kæmp.

"I may be a fool, but I intend to be a live fool." Mat hesitated, looking sideways at Rand. "Look, I know you came along to help me, and I am grateful. I really am. But you just are not the same anymore. You understand that, don't you?" He waited as if he expected an answer. None came. Finally he vanished into the trees, back toward the camp.

"wʌɾ əbaʊt ju?" ɹænd æskt.

"What about you?" Rand asked.

pɛɹɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, ʃæɡi kɝlz swɪŋɪŋ. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ, ɹænd. jə ɑɹ ðə seɪm, bʌt ðən əɡɛn, jə ɑɹənt. ə mæn tʃænəlɪŋ; maɪ mʌðɝ juz tə fɹaɪɾən mi wɪð ðæt, wən aɪ wɑz lɪɾəl. aɪ dʒʌs də nɑt noʊ." hi stʃɹɛtʃt aʊɾ ɪz hæn ən tʌtʃt ə kɔɹnɝ ə ðə bænɝ. "aɪ θɪŋk aɪ wəd bɝn ðɪs, əɹ bɛɹi ɪt, ɪf aɪ wɝ ju. ðən aɪd ɹʌn soʊ fɑɹ, soʊ fæst, noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ wəɾ ɛvɝ faɪn mi. mæt wɑz ɹaɪɾ əbaʊt ðæt." hi stʊɾ ʌp, skwɪntɪŋ ət ðə wɛstɝn skaɪ, bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə tɝn ɹɛd wɪð ðə sɪŋkɪŋ sʌn. "taɪm tə ɡɛt bæk tə ðə kæmp. jə θɪŋk ɑn wʌɾ aɪ sɛd, ɹænd. aɪd ɹʌn. bʌt meɪbi jə kæn ɹʌn. θɪŋk ə ðæt, tu." hɪz jɛloʊ aɪz sim tə lʊk ɪnwɝd, ən i saʊndəd taɪɝd. "səmtaɪmz jə kæn ɹʌn." ðən i wɑz ɡɔn, tu.

Perrin shook his head, shaggy curls swinging. "I don't know, Rand. You are the same, but then again, you aren't. A man channeling; my mother used to frighten me with that, when I was little. I just do not know." He stretched out his hand and touched a corner of the banner. "I think I would burn this, or bury it, if I were you. Then I'd run so far, so fast, no Aes Sedai would ever find me. Mat was right about that." He stood up, squinting at the western sky, beginning to turn red with the sinking sun. "Time to get back to the camp. You think on what I said, Rand. I'd run. But maybe you can't run. Think of that, too." His yellow eyes seemed to look inward, and he sounded tired. "Sometimes you can't run." Then he was gone, too.

ɹænd nɛl ðɛɹ, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə bænɝ spɹɛɾ aʊɾ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. "wɛl, səmtaɪmz jə kən ɹʌn," hi mʌɾɝd. "oʊnli, meɪbi ʃi ɡeɪv mi ðɪs tə meɪk mi ɹʌn. meɪbi ʃiz sʌmθɪŋ weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ mi, ɪf aɪ ɹʌn. aɪ woʊn də wʌt ʃi wɑns. aɪ woʊnt. əl bɛɹi ɪt ɹaɪt hɪɹ. bʌt ʃi sɛd maɪ laɪf meɪ dɪpɛn ɑn ɪt, ən ɛɛs sədaɪ nɛvɝ laɪ soʊ jə kən si ɪt. . . ." sʌɾənli hɪz ʃoʊldɝz ʃʊk wɪð saɪlən læftɝ. "naʊ aɪm tɔkɪŋ tə maɪsɛlf. meɪbi aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ mæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi."

Rand knelt there, staring at the banner spread out on the ground. "Well, sometimes you can run," he muttered. "Only, maybe she gave me this to make me run. Maybe she has something waiting for me, if I run. I won't do what she wants. I won't. I'll bury it right here. But she said my life may depend on it, and Aes Sedai never lie so you can see it. . . ." Suddenly his shoulders shook with silent laughter. "Now I'm talking to myself. Maybe I am going mad already."

wən i ɹɪtɝn tə ðə kæmp, hi kæɹid ðə bænɝ ɹæpt ɪn ðə kænvəs wʌns mɔɹ, taɪd wɪð nɑts lɛs nit ðən mɔɪɹeɪnz hæd bɪn.

When he returned to the camp, he carried the banner wrapped in the canvas once more, tied with knots less neat than Moiraine's had been.

ðə laɪt hæd bɪɡʌn tə feɪl ən ðə ʃædoʊ ʌv ðə ɹɪm kʌvɝd hæf ðə hɑloʊ. ðə soʊlʒɝz wɝ sɛɾəlɪŋ ɪn, ɔl wɪð ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz baɪ ðɛɹ saɪdz, lænsɪz pɹɑp tə hænd. mæt ən pɛɹɪn wɝ bɛɾɪŋ daʊn əlɔŋsaɪd ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz. ɹænd ɡeɪv əm ə sæd lʊk, ðən fɛtʃt ɹɛd, stændɪŋ wɛɹ i hæd bɪn lɛft wɪð ɪz ɹeɪnz dæŋɡəlɪŋ, ən wɛn tə ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə hɑloʊ, wɛɹ hʊɹɪn hæd dʒɔɪn lɔɪəl. ði oʊɡiɝ hæd ɡɪvən oʊvɝ ɹɛɾɪŋ ən wɑz ɪɡzæmɪnɪŋ ðə hæf-bɛɹid stoʊn ɑn wɪtʃ i hæd bɪn sɪɾɪŋ, tʃɹeɪsɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ ɑn ðə stoʊn wɪð ðə lɔŋ stɛm ə hɪz paɪp.

The light had begun to fail and the shadow of the rim covered half the hollow. The soldiers were settling in, all with their horses by their sides, lances propped to hand. Mat and Perrin were bedding down alongside their horses. Rand gave them a sad look, then fetched Red, standing where he had been left with his reins dangling, and went to the other side of the hollow, where Hurin had joined Loial. The Ogier had given over reading and was examining the half-buried stone on which he had been sitting, tracing something on the stone with the long stem of his pipe.

hʊɹɪn stʊɾ ən ɡeɪv ɹænd sʌmθɪŋ dʒʌst ʃɔɹɾ ʌv ə baʊ. "hoʊp jə doʊn maɪn mi meɪkɪŋ maɪ bɛd hɪɹ, lɔɹd - ʌ - ɹænd. aɪ wɑz dʒʌs lɪsnɪŋ tə ðə bɪldɝ hɪɹ."

Hurin stood and gave Rand something just short of a bow. "Hope you don't mind me making my bed here, Lord - uh - Rand. I was just listening to the Builder here."

"ðɛɹ jə ɑɹ, ɹænd," lɔɪəl sɛd. "ju noʊ, aɪ θɪŋk ðɪs stoʊn wɑz wɝkt wʌns. si, ɪts wɛðɝd, bʌɾ ɪt lʊks əz ɪf ɪt wɑz ə kɑləm ə səm kaɪnd. ən ðəɹ ɑɹ mɑɹkɪŋz, ɔlsoʊ. aɪ kæn kwaɪt meɪk əm aʊt, bʌt ðeɪ lʊk fəmɪljɝ, sʌmhaʊ."

"There you are, Rand," Loial said. "You know, I think this stone was worked once. See, it's weathered, but it looks as if it was a column of some kind. And there are markings, also. I can't quite make them out, but they look familiar, somehow."

"meɪbi jəl bi eɪbəl tə si ðɛm bɛɾɝ ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ," ɹænd sɛd. hi pʊl ðə sæɾəlbæɡz fɹəm ɹɛd. "aɪl bi ɡlæɾ ə jəɹ kʌmpəni, hʊɹɪn." aɪm ɡlæɾ ʌv ɛnibəɾiz kʌmpəni hu ɪzən əfɹeɪɾ ə mi. haʊ mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ kən aɪ hæv ɪt, ðoʊ?

"Maybe you'll be able to see them better in the morning," Rand said. He pulled the saddlebags from Red. "I'll be glad of your company, Hurin." I'm glad of anybody's company who isn't afraid of me. How much longer can I have it, though?

hi ʃɪftəɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪndə wʌn saɪɾ ə ðə sæɾəlbæɡz - spɛɹ ʃɝts ən bɹitʃɪz ən wʊlən stɑkɪŋz, soʊɪŋ kɪt, tɪndɝ bɑks, tɪn pleɪɾ ən kʌp, ə ɡɹinwʊd bɑks wɪð naɪf ən fɔɹk ən spun, ə pækəɾ ə dʒɹaɪd miɾ ən flætbɹɛd fəɹ ɪmɝdʒənsi ɹæʃənz, ən ɔl ði ʌðɝ tʃɹævəlɝz nəsəsɹiz - ðən stʌf ðə kænvəs-ɹæp bænɝ ɪndə ði ɛmpti pɑkət. ɪt bʌlʒd, ðə stʃɹæps bɛɹli ɹitʃɪŋ ðə bʌkəlz, bʌt ðɛn, ði ʌðɝ saɪd bʌlʒd naʊ, tu. ɪt wəd du.

He shifted everything into one side of the saddlebags - spare shirts and breeches and woolen stockings, sewing kit, tinder box, tin plate and cup, a greenwood box with knife and fork and spoon, a packet of dried meat and flatbread for emergency rations, and all the other traveler's necessaries - then stuffed the canvas-wrapped banner into the empty pocket. It bulged, the straps barely reaching the buckles, but then, the other side bulged now, too. It would do.

lɔɪəl ən hʊɹɪn sim tə sɛns ɪz mud, livɪŋ ɪm ɪn saɪləns waɪl i stʃɹɪp sæɾəl ən bɹaɪɾəl fɹəm ɹɛd, ɹʌb ðə bɪɡ beɪ daʊn wɪð tʌfs ʌv ɡɹæs tɔɹn fɹəm ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ðən ɹəsɑɾəld hɪm. ɹænd ɹəfjuz ðɛɹ ɔfɝ ə fud; hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk i cʊɾə stʌmɑtʃt ðə bɛs mil i hæɾ ɛvɝ sin dʒʌs ðɛn. ɔl θɹi ʌv əm meɪd ðɛɹ bɛdz ðəɹ bɪsaɪd ðə stoʊn, ə sɪmpəl mæɾɝ ʌv ə blæŋkət foʊldəd fəɹ ə pɪloʊ ən kloʊk tə kʌvɝ.

Loial and Hurin seemed to sense his mood, leaving him in silence while he stripped saddle and bridle from Red, rubbed the big bay down with tufts of grass torn from the ground, then resaddled him. Rand refused their offer of food; he did not think he could have stomached the best meal he had ever seen just then. All three of them made their beds there beside the stone, a simple matter of a blanket folded for a pillow and cloak to cover.

ðə kæmp wɑz saɪlənt naʊ, bʌt ɹænd leɪ əweɪk pæs ðə fɔl ə fʊl dɑɹk. hɪz maɪn dɑɹɾɪd bæk ən fɔɹθ. ðə bænɝ. wʌɾ ɪz ʃi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk mi du? ðə vɪlədʒ. wʌt kəd kɪl ə feɪd laɪk ðæt? wɝst ʌv ɔl, ðə haʊs ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ. dɪɾ ɪt ɹɪli hæpən? æm aɪ ɡoʊɪŋ mæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi? də aɪ ɹʌn, əɹ də aɪ steɪ? aɪ hæv tə steɪ. aɪ hæv tə hɛlp mæt faɪn ðə dæɡɝ.

The camp was silent now, but Rand lay awake past the fall of full dark. His mind darted back and forth. The banner. What is she trying to make me do? The village. What could kill a Fade like that? Worst of all, the house in the village. Did it really happen? Am I going mad already? Do I run, or do I stay? I have to stay. I have to help Mat find the dagger.

ən ɪɡzɔstəd slip faɪnəli keɪm, ən wɪð slip, ənbɪddən, ðə vɔɪd sɝaʊndəd hɪm, flɪkɝɪŋ wɪð ən ənizi ɡloʊ ðət dɪstɝbd ɪz dʒɹimz.

An exhausted sleep finally came, and with sleep, unbidden, the void surrounded him, flickering with an uneasy glow that disturbed his dreams.

pdən feɪn stɛɹd nɔɹθwɝɾ aʊɾ ɪndə ðə naɪt, pæs ði oʊnli faɪɝ ɪn ɪz kæmp, smaɪlɪŋ ə fɪkst smaɪl ðət nɛvɝ tʌtʃt ɪz aɪz. hi stɪl θɔɾ ə hɪmsɛlf əz pdən feɪn - pdən feɪn wɑz ðə kɔɹ ə hɪm - bʌɾ i hæd bɪn tʃeɪnʒd, ən i nu ɪt. hi nu mɛni θɪŋz, naʊ, mɔɹ ðən ɛni ʌv ɪz oʊl mæstɝz kəd səspɛkt. hi hæd bɪn ə dɑɹkfɹɛn lɔŋ jɪɹz bɪfɔɹ bælzəmən sʌmən ɪm ən sɛɾ ɪm ɑn ðə tʃɹæk ə ðə θɹi jʌŋ mɛn fɹəm ɛmənz fild, dɪstɪlɪŋ wʌɾ i nu ʌv ðɛm, dɪstɪlɪŋ hɪm, ən fiɾɪŋ ði ɛsəns bæk soʊ ðəɾ i kəd fil ðɛm, smɛl wɛɹ ðeɪ hæd bɪn, fɑloʊ wɛɹɛvɝ ðeɪ ɹæn. ɪspɛʃli ðə wʌn. ə pɑɹɾ ə hɪm stɪl kɹɪnʒd, ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ wʌt bælzəmən hæd dʌn tə hɪm, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ə smɔl pɑɹt, hɪɾən, səpɹɛst. hi wɑz tʃeɪnʒd. fɑloʊɪŋ ðə θɹi hæd lɛɾ ɪm ɪndə ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ. hi hæd nɑt wɑntəd tə ɡoʊ, bʌɾ i hæd hæd tə oʊbeɪ. ðɛn. ən ɪn ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ. . . .

Padan Fain stared northward out into the night, past the only fire in his camp, smiling a fixed smile that never touched his eyes. He still thought of himself as Padan Fain - Padan Fain was the core of him - but he had been changed, and he knew it. He knew many things, now, more than any of his old masters could suspect. He had been a Darkfriend long years before Ba'alzamon summoned him and set him on the track of the three young men from Emond's Field, distilling what he knew of them, distilling him, and feeding the essence back so that he could feel them, smell where they had been, follow wherever they ran. Especially the one. A part of him still cringed, remembering what Ba'alzamon had done to him, but it was a small part, hidden, suppressed. He was changed. Following the three had led him into Shadar Logoth. He had not wanted to go, but he had had to obey. Then. And in Shadar Logoth. . . .

feɪn dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ ən fɪŋɡɝd ðə ɹubi-hɪltɪd dæɡɝ əɾ ɪz bɛlt. ðət hæd kʌm fɹəm ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ, tu. ɪt wɑz ði oʊnli wɛpən i kæɹid, ði oʊnli wʌn i niɾəd; ɪt fɛlt laɪk ə pɑɹɾ ə hɪm. hi wɑz hoʊl wɪðɪn hɪmsɛlf, naʊ. ðət wɑz ɔl ðət mæɾɝd.

Fain drew a deep breath and fingered the ruby-hilted dagger at his belt. That had come from Shadar Logoth, too. It was the only weapon he carried, the only one he needed; it felt like a part of him. He was whole within himself, now. That was all that mattered.

hi kæst ə ɡlæns tə iðɝ saɪɾ ə hɪz faɪɝ. ðə twɛlv dɑɹkfɹɛnz u wɝ lɛft, ðɛɹ wʌns-faɪn kloʊðz naʊ ɹʌmpəld ən dɝɾi, hʌɾəld ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs tə wʌn saɪd, stɛɹɪŋ nɑɾ ət ðə faɪɝ, bʌɾ ət hɪm. ɑn ði ʌðɝ skwɑɾɪd ɪz tʃɹɑləks, twɛnti ɪn nʌmbɝ, ði ɔl-tu-hjumən aɪz ɪn ðoʊz ænəməl-twɪstəd mɛnz feɪsəz fɑloʊɪŋ ɪz ɛvɹi muv laɪk maɪs wɑtʃɪŋ ə kæt.

He cast a glance to either side of his fire. The twelve Darkfriends who were left, their once-fine clothes now rumpled and dirty, huddled in the darkness to one side, staring not at the fire, but at him. On the other squatted his Trollocs, twenty in number, the all-too-human eyes in those animal-twisted men's faces following his every move like mice watching a cat.

ɪt hæd bɪn ə stʃɹʌɡəl ət fɝst, weɪkɪŋ itʃ mɔɹnɪŋ tə faɪn hɪmsɛlf nɑt kəmplitli hoʊl, tə faɪn ðə mɹdʒɹɑl bæk ɪn kəmænd, ɹeɪdʒɪŋ ən dɪmændɪŋ ðeɪ ɡoʊ nɔɹθ, tə ðə blaɪt, tə ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl. bʌt bɪt baɪ bɪt ðoʊz mɔɹnɪŋz ʌv wiknəs ɡɹu ʃɔɹɾɝ, əntɪl. . . . hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðə fil ə ðə hæmɝ ɪn ɪz hænd, dʒɹaɪvɪŋ ðə spaɪks ɪn, ən i smaɪld; ðɪs taɪm ɪt dɪd tʌtʃ ɪz aɪz, wɪð ðə dʒɔɪ ʌv swit mɛmɹi.

It had been a struggle at first, waking each morning to find himself not completely whole, to find the Myrddraal back in command, raging and demanding they go north, to the Blight, to Shayol Ghul. But bit by bit those mornings of weakness grew shorter, until. . . . He remembered the feel of the hammer in his hand, driving the spikes in, and he smiled; this time it did touch his eyes, with the joy of sweet memory.

wipɪŋ fɹəm ðə dɑɹk kɑɾ ɪz ɪɹ, ən ɪz smaɪl feɪɾəd. aɪ ʃəd nɛvɝ əv lɛt ðə tʃɹɑləks teɪk soʊ mɛni. ən ɪntaɪɝ vɪlədʒ tə sloʊ ðɛm daʊn. ɪf ðoʊz fju haʊsəz ət ðə fɛɹi hæd nɑt bɪn dɪzɝɾɪd, pɝhæps. . . . bʌt tʃɹɑləks wɝ ɡɹiɾi baɪ neɪtʃɝ, ən ɪn ðə jufɔɹiə ʌv wɑtʃɪŋ ðə mɹdʒɹɑl daɪ, hi hæd nɑt peɪɾ ətɛnʃən əz i ʃʊd.

Weeping from the dark caught his ear, and his smile faded. I should never have let the Trollocs take so many. An entire village to slow them down. If those few houses at the ferry had not been deserted, perhaps. . . . But Trollocs were greedy by nature, and in the euphoria of watching the Myrddraal die, he had not paid attention as he should.

hi ɡlænst ət ðə tʃɹɑləks. ɛni wʌn ə ðɛm wɑz nɪɹli twaɪs əz tɔl əz hi, stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə bɹeɪk ɪm tə flɪndɝz wɪð wʌn hænd, jɛt ðeɪ ɛdʒ bæk, stɪl kɹaʊtʃɪŋ. "kɪl ðɛm. ɔl. jə meɪ fid, bʌt ðən meɪk ə paɪl ʌv ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðət ɹɪmeɪnz - fəɹ əɹ fɹɛnz tə faɪnd. pʊt ðə hɛdz ɑn tɑp. nitli, naʊ." hi læft, ən kʌɾ ɪɾ ɔf ʃɔɹt. "ɡoʊ!"

He glanced at the Trollocs. Any one of them was nearly twice as tall as he, strong enough to break him to flinders with one hand, yet they edged back, still crouching. "Kill them. All. You may feed, but then make a pile of everything that remains - for our friends to find. Put the heads on top. Neatly, now." He laughed, and cut it off short. "Go!"

ðə tʃɹɑləks skɹæmbəld əweɪ, dʒɹɔɪŋ saɪð-laɪk sɔɹdz ən ɹeɪzɪŋ spaɪkt æksiz. ɪn moʊməns ʃɹiks ən bɛloʊz ɹoʊz fɹəm wɛɹ ðə vɪlɪdʒɝz wɝ baʊnd. pliz fəɹ mɝsi ən tʃɪlʒɹənz skɹimz wɝ kʌɾ ɔf baɪ sɑləd θʌdz ən ənplɛzən skwɪʃɪŋ nɔɪzɪz, laɪk mɛlənz biɪŋ bɹoʊkən.

The Trollocs scrambled away, drawing scythe-like swords and raising spiked axes. In moments shrieks and bellows rose from where the villagers were bound. Pleas for mercy and children's screams were cut off by solid thuds and unpleasant squishing noises, like melons being broken.

feɪn tɝn ɪz bæk ɑn ðə kækɑfəni tə lʊk əɾ ɪz dɑɹkfɹɛnz. ðeɪ wɝ hɪz, tu, bɑɾi ən soʊl. sətʃ soʊlz əz ðeɪ hæd lɛft. ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðɛm wɑz maɪɹɾ əz dipli əz i hæd bɪn, bɪfɔɹ i faʊn ɪz weɪ aʊt. ɛvɹi wʌn wɪð noʊwɛɹ tə ɡoʊ ɪksɛp tə fɑloʊ hɪm. ðɛɹ aɪz klʌŋ tə fɪɹfəl, pliɾɪŋ. "ju θɪŋk ðəl ɡɹoʊ hʌŋɡɹi əɡɛn bɪfɔɹ wi faɪn ənʌðɝ vɪlədʒ əɹ ə fɑɹm? ðeɪ meɪ. jə θɪŋk əl bi lɛɾɪŋ əm əv səm mɔɹ ə ju? wɛl, pɝhæps wʌn əɹ tu. ðəɹ ɑɹən ɛni mɔɹ hɔɹsəz tə spɛɹ."

Fain turned his back on the cacophony to look at his Darkfriends. They were his, too, body and soul. Such souls as they had left. Every one of them was mired as deeply as he had been, before he found his way out. Every one with nowhere to go except to follow him. Their eyes clung to fearful, pleading. "You think they will grow hungry again before we find another village or a farm? They may. You think I will be letting them have some more of you? Well, perhaps one or two. There aren't any more horses to spare."

"ði ʌðɝz wɝ oʊnli kɑmənɝz," wʌn wʊmən mænədʒd ɪn ən ənstɛɾi vɔɪs. dɝt stʃɹikt əɹ feɪs əbʌv ə faɪnli kʌt dʒɹɛs ðət mɑɹkt əɹ əz ə mɝtʃənt, ən wɛlθi. smɪɹz steɪn ðə ɡʊd ɡɹeɪ klɔθ, ən ə lɔŋ tɛɹ mɑɹɾ əɹ skɝt. "ðeɪ wɝ pɛzəns. wɪv sɝvd - aɪ hæv sɝvd - "

"The others were only commoners," one woman managed in an unsteady voice. Dirt streaked her face above a finely cut dress that marked her as a merchant, and wealthy. Smears stained the good gray cloth, and a long tear marred her skirt. "They were peasants. We have served - I have served - "

feɪn kʌɾ əɹ ɔf, hɪz izi toʊn meɪkɪŋ ɪz wɝdz ɔl ðə hɑɹɾɝ. "wʌɾ ɑɹ ju, tə mi? lɛs ðən pɛzəns. hɝd kæɾəl fəɹ ðə tʃɹɑləks, pɝhæps? ɪf jə wɑnə lɪv, kæɾəl, jə mʌs bi jusfəl."

Fain cut her off, his easy tone making his words all the harder. "What are you, to me? Less than peasants. Herd cattle for the Trollocs, perhaps? If you want to live, cattle, you must be useful."

ðə wʊmənz feɪs bɹoʊk. ʃi sɑbd, ən sʌɾənli ɔl ðə ɹɛst wɝ bæbəlɪŋ, tɛlɪŋ ɪm haʊ jusfəl ðeɪ wɝ, mɛn ən wɪmən u hæd hæɾ ɪnfluəns ən pəzɪʃən bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ wɝ kɔl tə fʊlfɪl ðɛɹ oʊðz ət fæl dæɹə. ðeɪ spɪld aʊt ðə neɪmz ʌv ɪmpɔɹɾənt, paʊɝfəl pipəl hum ðeɪ nu ɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz, ɪn kɛɹhin, ən ʌðɝ lænz. ðeɪ bæbəld ə ðə nɑlədʒ ðeɪ əloʊn hæɾ ə ðɪs læn əɹ ðæt, ʌv pəlɪɾəkəl sɪtʃueɪʃənz, əlaɪənsəz, ɪntʃɹiɡz, ɔl ðə θɪŋz ðeɪ kəd tɛl ɪm ɪf i lɛɾ əm sɝv hɪm. ðə nɔɪz ə ðɛm blɛndəd wɪð ðə saʊnz ə ðə tʃɹɑləks' slɔɾɝ ən fɪt ɹaɪɾ ɪn.

The woman's face broke. She sobbed, and suddenly all the rest were babbling, telling him how useful they were, men and women who had had influence and position before they were called to fulfill their oaths at Fal Dara. They spilled out the names of important, powerful people whom they knew in the Borderlands, in Cairhien, and other lands. They babbled of the knowledge they alone had of this land or that, of political situations, alliances, intrigues, all the things they could tell him if he let them serve him. The noise of them blended with the sounds of the Trollocs' slaughter and fit right in.

feɪn ɪɡnɔɹɾ ɔl ʌv ɪt - hi hæd noʊ fɪɹ ə tɝnɪŋ ɪz bæk ɑn ðɛm, nɑt sɪns ðeɪ hæd sin ðə feɪd dɛlt wɪð - ən wɛn tə hɪz pɹaɪz. nilɪŋ, hi ɹæn ɪz hænz oʊvɝ ði ɔɹneɪt, ɡoʊldən tʃɛst, filɪŋ ðə paʊɝ lɑkt ɪnsaɪd. hi hæd tə hæv ə tʃɹɑlɑk kæɹi ɪt - hi dɪd nɑt tʃɹʌs ðə hjumənz ɪnʌf tə loʊɾ ɪɾ ɑn ə hɔɹs ən pæksæɾəl; səm dʒɹimz ə paʊɝ maɪt bi stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə oʊvɝkʌm ivən fɪɹ ə hɪm, bʌt tʃɹɑləks nɛvɝ dʒɹimd ʌv ɛniθɪŋ ɪksɛp kɪlɪŋ - ən i hæd nɑt jɛt pʌzəld aʊt haʊ tə oʊpən ɪt. bʌt ðət wəd kʌm. ɛvɹiθɪŋ wəd kʌm. ɛvɹiθɪŋ.

Fain ignored all of it - he had no fear of turning his back on them, not since they had seen the Fade dealt with - and went to his prize. Kneeling, he ran his hands over the ornate, golden chest, feeling the power locked inside. He had to have a Trolloc carry it - he did not trust the humans enough to load it on a horse and packsaddle; some dreams of power might be strong enough to overcome even fear of him, but Trollocs never dreamed of anything except killing - and he had not yet puzzled out how to open it. But that would come. Everything would come. Everything.

ənʃiðɪŋ ðə dæɡɝ, hi leɪɾ ɪɾ ətɑp ðə tʃɛs bɪfɔɹ sɛɾəlɪŋ hɪmsɛlf daʊn bɪsaɪd ðə faɪɝ. ðət bleɪd wɑz ə bɛɾɝ ɡɑɹd ðən tʃɹɑlɑk əɹ hjumən. ðeɪ hæɾ ɔl sin wʌt hæpənd wən i juzd ɪt, wʌns; nʌn wəd kʌm wɪðɪn ə spæn ə ðət bɛɹd bleɪd wɪθaʊɾ ɪz kəmænd, ən ðən ɹɪlʌktənli.

Unsheathing the dagger, he laid it atop the chest before settling himself down beside the fire. That blade was a better guard than Trolloc or human. They had all seen what happened when he used it, once; none would come within a span of that bared blade without his command, and then reluctantly.

laɪɪŋ ðəɹ ɪn ɪz blæŋkəts, hi stɛɹd nɔɹθwɝd. hi kəd nɑt fil ælθɹ, naʊ; ðə dɪstəns bɪtwin əm wɑz tu ɡɹeɪt. əɹ pɝhæps ælθɹ wɑz duɪŋ ɪz vænɪʃɪŋ tʃɹɪk. səmtaɪmz, ɪn ðə kip, ðə bɔɪ hæd sʌɾənli vænɪʃt fɹəm feɪnz sɛnsɪz. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ haʊ, bʌɾ ɔlweɪz ælθɹ keɪm bæk, dʒʌst əz sʌɾənli əz i hæd ɡɔn. hi wəd kʌm bæk ðɪs taɪm, tu.

Lying there in his blankets, he stared northward. He could not feel al'Thor, now; the distance between them was too great. Or perhaps al'Thor was doing his vanishing trick. Sometimes, in the keep, the boy had suddenly vanished from Fain's senses. He did not know how, but always al'Thor came back, just as suddenly as he had gone. He would come back this time, too.

"ðɪs taɪm jə kʌm tə mi, ɹænd ælθɹ. bɪfɔɹ, aɪ fɑloʊd jə laɪk ə dɔɡ dʒɹɪvən ɑn ðə tʃɹeɪl, bʌt naʊ jə fɑloʊ mi." hɪz læftɝ wɑz ə kækəl ðəɾ ivən i nu wɑz mæd, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt kɛɹ. mædnəs wɑz ə pɑɹɾ ə hɪm, tu. "kʌm tə mi, ælθɹ. ðə dæns ɪz nɑɾ ivən bɪɡʌn jɛt. wɪl dæns ɑn toʊmən hɛd, ən əl bi fɹi ʌv ju. əl si jə dɛɾ ət læst."

"This time you come to me, Rand al'Thor. Before, I followed you like a dog driven on the trail, but now you follow me." His laughter was a cackle that even he knew was mad, but he did not care. Madness was a part of him, too. "Come to me, al'Thor. The dance is not even begun yet. We'll dance on Toman Head, and I'll be free of you. I'll see you dead at last."


tʃæptɝ twɛlv


CHAPTER 12

woʊvən ɪn ðə pæɾɝn


Woven in the Pattern

ɛɡwin hɝiɾ æftɝ nɪneɪiv təwɔɹd ðə nɑɾ ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ ɝaʊn ði æmɪɝlɪn sits hɔɹs-bɔɹn pɑlɑnkwɪn, hɝ dɪzaɪɝ tə noʊ wʌt hæd kɑz ðə tɝmɔɪl ɪn fæl dæɹə kɛpt aʊtweɪɪŋ ivən əɹ wɝi oʊvɝ ɹænd. hi wɑz bɪɑn əɹ ɹitʃ, fəɹ ðə moʊmənt. bɛlə, hɝ ʃæɡi mɛɹ, wɑz wɪð ði ɛɛs sədaɪz hɔɹsəz, ən nɪneɪivz maʊnt, tu.

Egwene hurried after Nynaeve toward the knot of Aes Sedai around the Amyrlin Seat's horse-borne palanquin, her desire to know what had caused the turmoil in Fal Dara kept outweighing even her worry over Rand. He was beyond her reach, for the moment. Bela, her shaggy mare, was with the Aes Sedai's horses, and Nynaeve's mount, too.

ðə wɔɹɾɝz, hænz ɑn sɔɹd hɪls ən aɪz sɝtʃɪŋ ɛvɹiwɛɹ, meɪɾ ə stil sɝkəl ɝaʊn ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ðə pɑlɑnkwɪn. ðeɪ wɝ ən aɪlən ə ɹɛləɾɪv kɑm ɪn ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd, wɛɹ ʃaɪnɝən soʊlʒɝz stɪl ɹæn əmɪd ðə kips hɔɹəfaɪɾ ɪnhæbəɾənts. ɛɡwin pʊʃt ɪn bɪsaɪd nɪneɪiv - ðə tu ʌv əm ɔl bʌɾ ɪɡnɔɹɾ æftɝ ə sɪŋɡəl ʃɑɹp ɡlæns fɹəm ðə wɔɹɾɝz; ɔl nu ðeɪ wəd bi livɪŋ wɪð ði æmɪɝlɪn - ən kɑɾ ɪnʌf ɪn ðə kɹaʊdz mɝmɝz tə lɝn ʌv ən æɹoʊ ðət hæd flæʃt simɪŋli fɹəm noʊwɛɹ ən ə boʊmən jɛɾ ənkɔt.

The Warders, hands on sword hilts and eyes searching everywhere, made a steel circle around the Aes Sedai and the palanquin. They were an island of relative calm in the courtyard, where Shienaran soldiers still ran amid the keep's horrified inhabitants. Egwene pushed in beside Nynaeve - the two of them all but ignored after a single sharp glance from the Warders; all knew they would be leaving with the Amyrlin - and caught enough in the crowd's murmurs to learn of an arrow that had flashed seemingly from nowhere and a bowman yet uncaught.

ɛɡwin stɑpt, waɪd-aɪd, tu ʃɑkt ivən tə θɪŋk ðət ʃi wɑz sɝaʊndəd baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ən ətɛmpt ɑn ðə laɪf ə ði æmɪɝlɪn sit. ɪt wɛn bɪɑn θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv.

Egwene stopped, wide-eyed, too shocked even to think that she was surrounded by Aes Sedai. An attempt on the life of the Amyrlin Seat. It went beyond thinking of.

ði æmɪɝlɪn sæɾ ɪn əɹ pɑlɑnkwɪn wɪð ðə kɝɾənz dʒɹɔn bæk, ðə blʌdsteɪn ɹɪp ɪn əɹ sliv dʒɹɔɪŋ ɔl aɪz, ən feɪs daʊn lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ. "ju wɪl faɪn ðə boʊmən əɹ jəl nɑt, maɪ sʌn. iðɝ weɪ, maɪ bɪznəs ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn ɪz əz ɝdʒən əz ðəɾ ʌv ɪŋtʃɹ ɑn ɪz kwɛst. aɪ liv naʊ."

The Amyrlin sat in her palanquin with the curtains drawn back, the bloodstained rip in her sleeve drawing all eyes, and faced down Lord Agelmar. "You will find the bowman or you will not, my son. Either way, my business in Tar Valon is as urgent as that of Ingtar on his quest. I leave now."

"bʌt, mʌðɝ," eɪɡəlmɝ pɹətɛstəd, "ðɪs ətɛmpt ɑn jəɹ laɪf tʃeɪnʒəz ɛvɹiθɪŋ. wi stɪl də nɑt noʊ hu sɛn ðə mæn, əɹ waɪ. ən aʊɝ mɔɹ, ən əl əv ðə boʊmən ən ði ænsɝz fəɹ ju."

"But, Mother," Agelmar protested, "this attempt on your life changes everything. We still do not know who sent the man, or why. An hour more, and I will have the bowman and the answers for you."

ði æmɪɝlɪn bɑɹkt ə læf wɪð noʊ əmjuzmən ɪn ɪt. "jul nid slaɪɝ beɪɾ əɹ faɪnɝ nɛts tə kætʃ ðɪs fɪʃ, maɪ sʌn. baɪ ðə taɪm juv ðə mæn, ɪɾəl bi tu leɪɾ ɪn ðə deɪ fəɹ livɪŋ. ðəɹ ɑɹ tu mɛni hu wəd tʃɪɹ tə si mi dɛd fəɹ mi tə wɝi oʊvɝmək əbaʊt ðɪs wʌn. jə meɪ sɛn mi nuz ʌv wʌt jə faɪnd, ɪf jə faɪn ɛniθɪŋ əɾ ɔl." hɝ aɪz tʃɹævəld ɝaʊn ðə taʊɝz oʊvɝlʊkɪŋ ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd, ən ðə ɹæmpɑɹts ən ɑɹtʃɝz' bælkəniz, stɪl dʒæmd wɪð pipəl, ðoʊ saɪlənt naʊ. ði æɹoʊ hæd tə hæv kʌm fɹəm wʌn ə ðoʊz pleɪsəz. "aɪ θɪŋk ðɪs boʊmən ɪz ɔlɹɛɾi flɛd fɹəm fæl dæɹə."

The Amyrlin barked a laugh with no amusement in it. "You'll need slyer bait or finer nets to catch this fish, my son. By the time you have the man, it will be too late in the day for leaving. There are too many who would cheer to see me dead for me to worry overmuch about this one. You may send me news of what you find, if you find anything at all." Her eyes traveled around the towers overlooking the courtyard, and the ramparts and archers' balconies, still jammed with people, though silent now. The arrow had to have come from one of those places. "I think this bowman is already fled from Fal Dara."

"bʌt, mʌðɝ - "

"But, Mother - "

ðə wʊmən ɪn ðə pɑlɑnkwɪn kʌɾ ɪm ɔf wɪð ə ʃɑɹp dʒɛstʃɝ ə faɪnæləɾi. nɑɾ ivən ðə lɔɹɾ ə fæl dæɹə kəd pɹɛs ði æmɪɝlɪn sit tu fɑɹ. hɝ aɪz keɪm tə ɹɛst ɑn ɛɡwin ən nɪneɪiv, pɪɹsɪŋ aɪz ðət sim tə ɛɡwin tə bi siɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ əbaʊt hɝsɛlf ðət ʃi wɑntəd tə kip sikɹət. ɛɡwin tʊk ə stɛp bæk, ðən kɑt hɝsɛlf ən dʒɹɑpt ə kɝtsi, wʌndɝɪŋ ɪf ðət wɝ pɹɑpɝ; noʊ wʌn hæɾ ɛvɝ ɪkspleɪn tə hɝ ðə pɹoʊɾəkɑl ə miɾɪŋ ði æmɪɝlɪn sit. nɪneɪiv kɛpt əɹ bæk stʃɹeɪɾ ən ɹɪtɝn ði æmɪɝlɪnz stɛɹ, bʌt ʃi fʌmbəl fəɹ ɛɡwinz hæn ən ɡɹɪpt əz hɑɹɾ əz ɛɡwin dɪd.

The woman in the palanquin cut him off with a sharp gesture of finality. Not even the Lord of Fal Dara could press the Amyrlin Seat too far. Her eyes came to rest on Egwene and Nynaeve, piercing eyes that seemed to Egwene to be seeing everything about herself that she wanted to keep secret. Egwene took a step back, then caught herself and dropped a curtsy, wondering if that were proper; no one had ever explained to her the protocol of meeting the Amyrlin Seat. Nynaeve kept her back straight and returned the Amyrlin's stare, but she fumbled for Egwene's hand and gripped as hard as Egwene did.

"soʊ ðiz ɑɹ jəɹ tu, mɔɪɹeɪn," ði æmɪɝlɪn sɛd. mɔɪɹeɪn ɡeɪv ðə bɛɹəs nɑd, ən ði ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ tɝn tə stɛɹ ət ðə tu wɪmən fɹəm ɛmənz fild. ɛɡwin swɑloʊd. ðeɪ ɔl lʊkt əz ɪf ðeɪ nu θɪŋz, θɪŋz ʌðɝ pipəl dɪd nɑt, ən ɪt wɑz noʊ hɛlp əɾ ɔl tə noʊ ðət ðeɪ tʃɹuli dɪd. "jɛs, aɪ sɛns ə faɪn spɑɹk ɪn itʃ ə ðɛm. bʌt wʌt wɪl kɪndəl fɹəm ɪt? ðæts ðə kwɛstʃən, ɪzən ɪt?"

"So these are your two, Moiraine," the Amyrlin said. Moiraine gave the barest nod, and the other Aes Sedai turned to stare at the two women from Emond's Field. Egwene swallowed. They all looked as if they knew things, things other people did not, and it was no help at all to know that they truly did. "Yes, I sense a fine spark in each of them. But what will kindle from it? That's the question, isn't it?"

ɛɡwinz maʊθ fɛl dʒɹaɪ əz dʌst. ʃi hæd sin mæstɝ pædwɪn, ðə kɑɹpəntɝ bæk hoʊm, lʊk əɾ ɪz tulz mʌtʃ ðə seɪm weɪ əz ði æmɪɝlɪn wɑz lʊkɪŋ ət ðə tu ʌv ðɛm. ðɪs wʌn fəɹ ðɪs pɝpəs, ðət wʌn fəɹ ðæt.

Egwene's mouth felt dry as dust. She had seen Master Padwhin, the carpenter back home, look at his tools much the same way as the Amyrlin was looking at the two of them. This one for this purpose, that one for that.

ði æmɪɝlɪn sɛɾ əbɹʌpli, "ɪɾ ɪz taɪm wi wɝ ɡɔn. tə hɔɹs. lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ ən aɪ kən seɪ wʌt nidz bi sɛd wɪθaʊt jə ɔl ɡɔkɪŋ laɪk nɑvəsɪz ɑn ə fɹideɪ. tə hɔɹs!"

The Amyrlin said abruptly, "It is time we were gone. To horse. Lord Agelmar and I can say what needs be said without you all gawking like novices on a freeday. To horse!"

əɾ əɹ kəmæn ðə wɔɹɾɝz skæɾɝd tə ðɛɹ maʊns, stɪl wɛɹi, ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɔl bʌt lin, ɡlaɪɾɪd əweɪ fɹəm ðə pɑlɑnkwɪn tə ðɛɹ oʊn hɔɹsəz. əz ɛɡwin ən nɪneɪiv tɝn tə oʊbeɪ, ə sɝvən əpɪɹɾ ət lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝz ʃoʊldɝ wɪð ə sɪlvɝ tʃælɪs. eɪɡəlmɝ tʊk ɪt wɪð ə dɪsæɾəsfaɪd twɪs tə hɪz maʊθ.

At her command the Warders scattered to their mounts, still wary, and the Aes Sedai, all but Leane, glided away from the palanquin to their own horses. As Egwene and Nynaeve turned to obey, a servant appeared at Lord Agelmar's shoulder with a silver chalice. Agelmar took it with a dissatisfied twist to his mouth.

"wɪð ðɪs kʌp fɹəm maɪ hænd, mʌðɝ, teɪk maɪ wɪʃ ðət jə fɛɹ wɛl ɑn ðɪs deɪ, ən ɛvɹi. . . ."

"With this cup from my hand, Mother, take my wish that you fare well on this day, and every. . . ."

wʌtɛvɝ ɛls ðeɪ sɛd wɑz lɔs tə ɛɡwin əz ʃi skɹæmbəld ɑntu bɛlə. baɪ ðə taɪm ʃi hæd ɡɪvən ðə ʃæɡi mɛɹ ə pæt, ən ɝeɪnʒd əɹ skɝts, ðə pɑlɑnkwɪn wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi muvɪŋ təwɔɹd ði oʊpən ɡeɪts, ɪts hɔɹsəz stɛpɪŋ wɪθaʊt ɹeɪn əɹ lɛd. lin ɹoʊd bɪsaɪd ðə pɑlɑnkwɪn, hɝ stæf pɹɑpt əɾ əɹ stɝəp. ɛɡwin ən nɪneɪiv bɹɔt ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz əlɔŋ bɪhaɪnd wɪð ðə ɹɛst ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Whatever else they said was lost to Egwene as she scrambled onto Bela. By the time she had given the shaggy mare a pat, and arranged her skirts, the palanquin was already moving toward the open gates, its horses stepping without rein or lead. Leane rode beside the palanquin, her staff propped at her stirrup. Egwene and Nynaeve brought their horses along behind with the rest of the Aes Sedai.

ɹɔɹz ən tʃɪɹz fɹəm ðə kɹaʊdz laɪnɪŋ ðə taʊn stʃɹits ɡɹiɾəd ðə pɹəsɛʃən, ɔl bʌt dʒɹaʊnɪŋ ðə θʌndɝ ə ðə dʒɹʌmɝz ən ðə blɛɹ ə ðə tʃɹʌmpəɾɝz. wɔɹɾɝz lɛd ðə kɑləm, wɪð ðə bænɝ bɛɹɪŋ ðə waɪt fleɪm weɪvɪŋ ɪn ɹɪpəlz, ən ɹoʊd ɡɑɹɾ ɝaʊn ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, kipɪŋ ðə mæs ə pipəl bæk; ɑɹtʃɝz ən pɪkmɛn, ðə fleɪm blæzən ɑn ðɛɹ tʃɛsts, fɑloʊd bɪhaɪn ɪn pɹɪsaɪs ɹæŋks. ðə tʃɹʌmpəts fɛl saɪlən əz ðə kɑləm waʊn ɪts weɪ aʊɾ ə ðə taʊn ən tɝn saʊθwɝd, jɛt ðə saʊnz ə tʃɪɹɪŋ fɹəm wɪðɪn ðə taʊn fɑloʊd stɪl. ɛɡwin ɡlæns bæk ɔfən, əntɪl tʃɹiz ən hɪlz hɪd fæl dæɹəz wɔlz ən taʊɝz.

Roars and cheers from the crowds lining the town streets greeted the procession, all but drowning the thunder of the drummers and the blare of the trumpeters. Warders led the column, with the banner bearing the White Flame waving in ripples, and rode guard around the Aes Sedai, keeping the mass of people back; archers and pikemen, the Flame blazoned on their chests, followed behind in precise ranks. The trumpets fell silent as the column wound its way out of the town and turned southward, yet the sounds of cheering from within the town followed still. Egwene glanced back often, until trees and hills hid Fal Dara's walls and towers.

nɪneɪiv, ɹaɪɾɪŋ əlɔŋsaɪd, ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "ɹænd wɪl bi ɔl ɹaɪt. hiz lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹ ən twɛnti lænsɪz wɪð hɪm. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ðəɹ ɪz nʌθɪŋ jə kən də əbaʊɾ ɪt. nʌθɪŋ iðɝ ʌv əs kən du." ʃi ɡlæns təwɔɹd mɔɪɹeɪn; ði ɛɛs sədaɪz tʃɹɪm waɪt mɛɹ ən lænz tɔl blæk stæljən meɪɾ ən ɑd pɛɹ ɔf tə wʌn saɪd baɪ ðɛmsɛlvz. "nɑt jɛt."

Nynaeve, riding alongside, shook her head. "Rand will be all right. He has Lord Ingtar and twenty lances with him. In any case, there is nothing you can do about it. Nothing either of us can do." She glanced toward Moiraine; the Aes Sedai's trim white mare and Lan's tall black stallion made an odd pair off to one side by themselves. "Not yet."

ðə kɑləm æŋɡəld wɛstwɝɾ əz ɪt tʃɹævəld, ən ɪt dɪd nɑt kʌvɝ ðə ɡɹaʊn kwɪkli. ivən fʊtmən ɪn hæf ɑɹmɝ kəd nɑt muv fæs θɹu ðə ʃaɪnɝən hɪlz, nɑɾ ən meɪnteɪn ðə peɪs fəɹ lɔŋ. stɪl, ðeɪ pʊʃt əz hɑɹɾ əz ðeɪ kʊd.

The column angled westward as it traveled, and it did not cover the ground quickly. Even footmen in half armor could not move fast through the Shienaran hills, not and maintain the pace for long. Still, they pushed as hard as they could.

kæmps keɪm leɪɾ itʃ naɪt, ði æmɪɝlɪn əlaʊɪŋ noʊ stɑp əntɪl bɛɹli ɪnʌf laɪt ɹɪmeɪn tə pɪtʃ ðə tɛns, flæɾənd waɪt doʊmz dʒʌs tɔl ɪnʌf tə stæn ɪn. itʃ pɛɹ ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ fɹəm ðə seɪm ədʒɑ hæd wʌn, waɪl ði æmɪɝlɪn ən ðə kipɝ hæd tɛns tə ðɛmsɛlvz. mɔɪɹeɪn ʃɛɹd ðə tɛn ə hɝ tu sɪstɝz ə ðə blu. ðə soʊlʒɝz slɛpt ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn ɪn ðɛɹ oʊn ɛnkæmpmənt, ən ðə wɔɹɾɝz ɹæp ðɛmsɛlvz ɪn ðɛɹ kloʊks nɪɹ ðə tɛns ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tə hum ðeɪ wɝ bɑndəd. ðə tɛnt ʃɛɹd baɪ ðə ɹɛd sɪstɝz lʊkt ɑdli loʊnli wɪθaʊɾ ɛni wɔɹɾɝz, waɪl ðəɾ ə ðə ɡɹinz simd ɔlmoʊs fɛstɪv, ðə tu ɛɛs sədaɪ ɔfən sɪɾɪŋ aʊtsaɪd lɔŋ pæs dɑɹk tə tɔk wɪð ðə fɔɹ wɔɹɾɝz ðeɪ hæd bɹɔt bɪtwin ðɛm.

Camps came late each night, the Amyrlin allowing no stop until barely enough light remained to pitch the tents, flattened white domes just tall enough to stand in. Each pair of Aes Sedai from the same Ajah had one, while the Amyrlin and the Keeper had tents to themselves. Moiraine shared the tent of her two sisters of the Blue. The soldiers slept on the ground in their own encampment, and the Warders wrapped themselves in their cloaks near the tents of the Aes Sedai to whom they were bonded. The tent shared by the Red sisters looked oddly lonely without any Warders, while that of the Greens seemed almost festive, the two Aes Sedai often sitting outside long past dark to talk with the four Warders they had brought between them.

læn keɪm wʌns tə ðə tɛn ɛɡwin ʃɛɹd wɪð nɪneɪiv, teɪkɪŋ ðə wɪzdəm ɪndə ðə naɪɾ ə lɪɾəl dɪstəns əweɪ. ɛɡwin pɪɹɾ ɝaʊn ðə tɛn flæp tə wɑtʃ. ʃi kəd nɑt hɪɹ wʌt ðeɪ sɛd, ɪksɛp ðət nɪneɪiv ɪvɛntʃəwəli ɪɹʌptəɾ ɪn æŋɡɝ ən keɪm stɔkɪŋ bæk tə ɹæp hɝsɛlf ɪn əɹ blæŋkəts ən ɹəfjuz tə tɔk əɾ ɔl. ɛɡwin θɔɾ əɹ tʃiks wɝ wɛt, ðoʊ ʃi hɪɾ əɹ feɪs wɪð ə kɔɹnɝ ə hɝ blæŋkət. læn stʊd wɑtʃɪŋ ðə tɛn fɹəm ðə dɑɹknəs fəɹ ə lɔŋ taɪm bɪfɔɹ i wɛn əweɪ. æftɝ ðəɾ i dɪd nɑt kʌm əɡɛn.

Lan came once to the tent Egwene shared with Nynaeve, taking the Wisdom into the night a little distance away. Egwene peered around the tent flap to watch. She could not hear what they said, except that Nynaeve eventually erupted in anger and came stalking back to wrap herself in her blankets and refuse to talk at all. Egwene thought her cheeks were wet, though she hid her face with a corner of her blanket. Lan stood watching the tent from the darkness for a long time before he went away. After that he did not come again.

mɔɪɹeɪn dɪd nɑt kʌm nɪɹ ðɛm, ɡɪvɪŋ əm oʊnli ə nɑɾ ɪn pæsɪŋ. ʃi sim tə spɛn əɹ weɪkɪŋ aʊɝz spikɪŋ wɪð ði ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɔl bʌt ðə ɹɛd sɪstɝz, dʒɹɔɪŋ əm əsaɪd wʌn baɪ wʌn əz ðeɪ ɹoʊd. ði æmɪɝlɪn əlaʊd fju stɑps fəɹ ɹɛst, ən ðoʊz ʃɔɹt.

Moiraine did not come near them, giving them only a nod in passing. She seemed to spend her waking hours speaking with the other Aes Sedai, all but the Red sisters, drawing them aside one by one as they rode. The Amyrlin allowed few stops for rest, and those short.

"meɪbi ʃi dʌzn əv taɪm fəɹ əs ɛnimɔɹ," ɛɡwin əbzɝv sædli. mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz ðə wʌn ɛɛs sədaɪ ʃi nu. pɝhæps - ðoʊ ʃi dɪd nɑt laɪk tə ədmɪɾ ɪt - ði oʊnli wʌn ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ʃi kəd tʃɹʌst. "ʃi faʊn ʌs, ən wəɹ ɑn əɹ weɪ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn. aɪ səpoʊz ʃiz ʌðɝ θɪŋz tə kənsɝn hɝ, naʊ."

"Maybe she doesn't have time for us anymore," Egwene observed sadly. Moiraine was the one Aes Sedai she knew. Perhaps - though she did not like to admit it - the only one she was sure she could trust. "She found us, and we are on our way to Tar Valon. I suppose she has other things to concern her, now."

nɪneɪiv snɔɹɾɪd sɔfli. "aɪl bɪliv ʃiz dʌn wɪð əs wən ʃiz dɛd - əɹ wi ɑɹ. ʃiz slaɪ, ðət wʌn."

Nynaeve snorted softly. "I'll believe she is done with us when she's dead - or we are. She is sly, that one."

ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ keɪm tə ðɛɹ tɛnt. ɛɡwin ɔlmoʊs dʒʌmpt aʊɾ ə hɝ skɪn ðət fɝs naɪɾ aʊɾ ə fæl dæɹə, wən ðə tɛn flæp wɑz pʊʃt əsaɪɾ ən ə plʌmp, skwɛɹ-feɪst ɛɛs sədaɪ, wɪð ɡɹeɪɪŋ hɛɹ ən ə veɪɡli dɪstʃɹæktəd lʊk ɪn əɹ dɑɹk aɪz, dʌkt ɪndə ðɛɹ tɛnt. ʃi ɡlænst ət ðə læntɝn hæŋɪŋ ət ðə haɪəs pɔɪn ə ðə tɛnt, ən ðə fleɪm ɹoʊz ə lɪɾəl haɪɝ. ɛɡwin θɔt ʃi fɛl sʌmθɪŋ, θɔt ʃi ɔlmoʊst sɔ sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wən ðə fleɪm ɡɹu bɹaɪɾɝ. mɔɪɹeɪn hæd toʊld əɹ ðət wʌn deɪ - wən ʃi hæd mɔɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ - ʃi wəd bi eɪbəl tə si wən ənʌðɝ wʊmən tʃænəld, ən tə tɛl ə wʊmən u kəd tʃænəl ivən ɪf ʃi dɪd nʌθɪŋ.

Other Aes Sedai came to their tent. Egwene almost jumped out of her skin that first night out of Fal Dara, when the tent flap was pushed aside and a plump, square-faced Aes Sedai, with graying hair and a vaguely distracted look in her dark eyes, ducked into their tent. She glanced at the lantern hanging at the highest point of the tent, and the flame rose a little higher. Egwene thought she felt something, thought she almost saw something about the Aes Sedai when the flame grew brighter. Moiraine had told her that one day - when she had more training - she would be able to see when another woman channeled, and to tell a woman who could channel even if she did nothing.

"aɪ æm vɛɹɪn mæθwɪn," ðə wʊmən sɛd wɪð ə smaɪl. "æn jə ɑɹ ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ ən nɪneɪiv ælmɛɹə. fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, wɪtʃ wɑz wʌns meɪnɛðɝən. stʃɹɔŋ blʌd, ðæt. ɪt sɪŋz."

"I am Verin Mathwin," the woman said with a smile. "And you are Egwene al'Vere and Nynaeve al'Maera. From the Two Rivers, which was once Manetheren. Strong blood, that. It sings."

ɛɡwin ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ɡlænsɪz wɪð nɪneɪiv əz ðeɪ ɡɑt tə ðɛɹ fit.

Egwene exchanged glances with Nynaeve as they got to their feet.

"ɪz ðɪs ə sʌmənz tə ði æmɪɝlɪn sit?" ɛɡwin æskt.

"Is this a summons to the Amyrlin Seat?" Egwene asked.

vɛɹɪn læft. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hæɾ ə smʌdʒ ʌv ɪŋk ɑn əɹ noʊz. "oʊ, maɪ, noʊ. ði æmɪɝlɪn əz mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt θɪŋz tə dil wɪð ðən tu jʌŋ wɪmən u ɑɹ nɑɾ ivən nɑvəsɪz jɛt. ɔlðoʊ, jə nɛvɝ kən tɛl. jə boʊθ əv kənsɪɾɝəbəl pətɛnʃəl, ɪspɛʃli ju, nɪneɪiv. wʌn deɪ. . . ." ʃi pɔzd, ɹʌbɪŋ ə fɪŋɡɝ θɔtfəli ɹaɪɾ ətɑp ði ɪŋk smʌdʒ. "bʌt ðɪs ɪz nɑt wʌn deɪ. aɪm hɪɹ tə ɡɪv jə ə lɛsən, ɛɡwin. juv bɪn poʊkɪŋ ɪn əhɛɾ ə jɝsɛlf, aɪ fɪɹ."

Verin laughed. The Aes Sedai had a smudge of ink on her nose. "Oh, my, no. The Amyrlin has more important things to deal with than two young women who are not even novices yet. Although, you never can tell. You both have considerable potential, especially you, Nynaeve. One day. . . ." She paused, rubbing a finger thoughtfully right atop the ink smudge. "But this is not one day. I am here to give you a lesson, Egwene. You have been poking in ahead of yourself, I fear."

nɝvəsli, ɛɡwin lʊkt ət nɪneɪiv. "wʌɾ əv aɪ dʌn? nʌθɪŋ ðəɾ aɪm əwɛɹ ʌv."

Nervously, Egwene looked at Nynaeve. "What have I done? Nothing that I'm aware of."

"oʊ, nʌθɪŋ ɹɔŋ. nɑɾ ɪɡzækli. sʌmwʌt deɪnʒɝəs, pɝhæps, bʌt nɑɾ ɪɡzækli ɹɔŋ." vɛɹɪn loʊɝd hɝsɛlf tə ðə kænvəs flɔɹ, foʊldɪŋ əɹ lɛɡz ʌndɝ hɝ. "sɪt, boʊθ ə ju. sɪt. aɪ doʊn min tə kɹeɪn maɪ nɛk." ʃi ʃɪftəɾ ɝaʊn əntɪl ʃi hæɾ ə kʌmftəɹbəl pəzɪʃən. "sɪt."

"Oh, nothing wrong. Not exactly. Somewhat dangerous, perhaps, but not exactly wrong." Verin lowered herself to the canvas floor, folding her legs under her. "Sit, both of you. Sit. I don't mean to crane my neck." She shifted around until she had a comfortable position. "Sit."

ɛɡwin sɛɾəld kɹɔs-lɛɡəɾ əkɹɔs fɹəm ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən dɪɾ əɹ bɛs nɑt tə lʊk ət nɪneɪiv. noʊ nid tə lʊk ɡɪlti əntɪl aɪ noʊ ɪf aɪ æm. ən meɪbi nɑt ðɛn. "wʌɾ ɪz ɪɾ aɪv dʌn ðæts deɪnʒɝəs bʌt nɑɾ ɪɡzækli ɹɔŋ?"

Egwene settled cross-legged across from the Aes Sedai and did her best not to look at Nynaeve. No need to look guilty until I know if I am. And maybe not then. "What is it I've done that's dangerous but not exactly wrong?"

"waɪ, juv bɪn tʃænəlɪŋ ðə paʊɝ, tʃaɪld."

"Why, you've been channeling the Power, child."

ɛɡwin kəɾ oʊnli ɡeɪp. nɪneɪiv bɝst aʊt, "ðæɾ ɪz ɹɪdɪkjələs. waɪ ɑɹ wi ɡoʊɪŋ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn, ɪf nɑt fəɹ ðæt?"

Egwene could only gape. Nynaeve burst out, "That is ridiculous. Why are we going to Tar Valon, if not for that?"

"mɔɪɹeɪn əz . . . aɪ min, mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ hæz bɪn ɡɪvɪŋ mi lɛsənz," ɛɡwin mænədʒd.

"Moiraine has . . . I mean, Moiraine Sedai has been giving me lessons," Egwene managed.

vɛɹɪn hɛld ʌp əɹ hænz fəɹ kwaɪət, ən ðeɪ fɛl saɪlənt. ʃi maɪt sim veɪɡ, bʌt ʃi wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ, æftɝ ɔl. "tʃaɪld, dʒju θɪŋk ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪmiɾiətli titʃ ɛvɹi ɡɝl u sɛz ʃi wɑns tə bi wʌn ʌv əs haʊ tə tʃænəl? wɛl, aɪ səpoʊz jə ɑɹ nɑɾ ɪɡzækli ɛvɹi ɡɝl, bʌt dʒʌs ðə seɪm. . . ." ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd ɡɹeɪvli.

Verin held up her hands for quiet, and they fell silent. She might seem vague, but she was Aes Sedai, after all. "Child, do you think Aes Sedai immediately teach every girl who says she wants to be one of us how to channel? Well, I suppose you are not exactly every girl, but just the same. . . ." She shook her head gravely.

"ðɛn waɪ dɪd ʃi?" nɪneɪiv dɪmændəd. ðəɹ hæd bɪn noʊ lɛsənz fəɹ hɝ, ən ɛɡwin wɑz stɪl nɑt ʃʊɹ ɪf ɪt ɹæŋkəl nɪneɪiv əɹ nɑt.

"Then why did she?" Nynaeve demanded. There had been no lessons for her, and Egwene was still not sure if it rankled Nynaeve or not.

"bɪkɔz ɛɡwin hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi tʃænəld," vɛɹɪn sɛd peɪʃənli.

"Because Egwene had already channeled," Verin said patiently.

"soʊ. . . . soʊ hæv aɪ." nɪneɪiv dɪd nɑt saʊn hæpi əbaʊɾ ɪt.

"So. . . . So have I." Nynaeve did not sound happy about it.

"jɔɹ sɝkəmstænsəz ɑɹ dɪfɹənt, tʃaɪld. ðət jə ɑɹ stɪl əlaɪv ʃoʊz jə wɛðɝd ðə vɛɹiəs kɹaɪsiz, ən dɪɾ ɪɾ ɑn jəɹ oʊn. aɪ θɪŋk jə noʊ haʊ lʌki jə ɑɹ. ʌv ɛvɹi fɔɹ wɪmən fɔɹs tə də wʌt jə dɪd, oʊnli wʌn sɝvaɪvz. ʌv kɔɹs, waɪldɝz - " vɛɹɪn ɡɹɪməst. "fɝɡɪv mi, bʌɾ aɪm əfɹeɪd ðəɾ ɪz wʌt wi ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɔfən kɔl wɪmən hu, wɪθaʊɾ ɛni tʃɹeɪnɪŋ, hæv mænədʒ səm ɹʌf kəntʃɹoʊl - ɹændəm, ən bɛɹli ɪnʌf tə bi kɔl kəntʃɹoʊl, juʒəwəli, laɪk ju, bʌt stɪl kəntʃɹoʊl ʌv ə sɔɹt. waɪldɝz əv dɪfəkəltiz, ɪts tʃɹu. ɔlmoʊst ɔlweɪz ðeɪv bɪlt ʌp wɔlz tə kip ðɛmsɛlvz fɹəm noʊɪŋ wʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðeɪ wɝ duɪŋ, ən ðoʊz wɔlz ɪntɝfɪɹ wɪð kɑnʃəs kəntʃɹoʊl. ðə lɔŋɡɝ ðoʊz wɔlz əv tə bɪld, ðə hɑɹɾɝ ɪts tə tɛɹ əm daʊn, bʌɾ ɪf ðeɪ kən bi dɪmɑlɪʃt - wɛl, səm ə ðə moʊst ədɛp sɪstɝz ɛvɝ əv bɪn waɪldɝz."

"Your circumstances are different, child. That you are still alive shows you weathered the various crises, and did it on your own. I think you know how lucky you are. Of every four women forced to do what you did, only one survives. Of course, wilders - " Verin grimaced. "Forgive me, but I am afraid that is what we in the White Tower often call women who, without any training, have managed some rough control - random, and barely enough to be called control, usually, like you, but still control of a sort. Wilders have difficulties, it is true. Almost always they have built up walls to keep themselves from knowing what it was they were doing, and those walls interfere with conscious control. The longer those walls have to build, the harder it is to tear them down, but if they can be demolished - well, some of the most adept sisters ever have been wilders."

nɪneɪiv ʃɪftəɾ ɪɹɪɾəbli, ən lʊkt ət ði ɛntʃɹəns əz ɪf θɪŋkɪŋ ə livɪŋ.

Nynaeve shifted irritably, and looked at the entrance as if thinking of leaving.

"aɪ doʊn si wʌɾ ɛni ʌv ðəɾ əz tə də wɪð mi," ɛɡwin sɛd.

"I don't see what any of that has to do with me," Egwene said.

vɛɹɪn blɪŋkt ət hɝ, ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf wʌndɝɪŋ wɛɹ ʃi hæd kʌm fɹʌm. "wɪð ju? waɪ, nʌθɪŋ. jəɹ pɹɑbləm ɪz kwaɪt dɪfɹənt. moʊst ɡɝlz u wɑnə bɪkʌm ɛɛs sədaɪ - ivən moʊst ɡɝlz wɪð ðə siɾ ɪnsaɪd ðɛm, laɪk jə - ɑɹ əfɹeɪɾ ʌv ɪt, tu. ivən æftɝ ðeɪ ɹitʃ ðə taʊɝ, ivən æftɝ ðeɪv lɝnd wʌt tə də ən haʊ, fəɹ mʌnθs ðeɪ nid tə bi lɛd, stɛp baɪ stɛp, baɪ ə sɪstɝ, əɹ baɪ wʌn ə ði æksɛptɪd. bʌt nɑt ju. fɹəm wʌt mɔɪɹeɪn tɛlz mi, jə lɛpt ɪndə ɪɾ əz sun əz jə nu jə kʊd, fʌmbəlɪŋ jəɹ weɪ θɹu ðə dɑɹk wɪð nɛvɝ ə θɔɾ ʌv wɛðɝ ðəɹ wɑz ə bɑɾəmləs pɪɾ ʌndɝ jəɹ nɛkst stɛp. oʊ, ðəɹ əv bɪn ʌðɝz laɪk ju; jə ɑɹ nɑt junik. mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz wʌn hɝsɛlf. wʌns ʃi nu wʌt jə hæd dʌn, ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ fəɹ ɪt bʌt fəɹ əɹ tə bɪɡɪn titʃɪŋ ju. dɪd mɔɪɹeɪn nɛvɝ ɪkspleɪn ɛni ʌv ðɪs tə ju?"

Verin blinked at her, almost as if wondering where she had come from. "With you? Why, nothing. Your problem is quite different. Most girls who want to become Aes Sedai - even most girls with the seed inside them, like you - are afraid of it, too. Even after they reach the Tower, even after they've learned what to do and how, for months they need to be led, step by step, by a sister, or by one of the Accepted. But not you. From what Moiraine tells me, you leaped into it as soon as you knew you could, fumbling your way through the dark with never a thought of whether there was a bottomless pit under your next step. Oh, there have been others like you; you are not unique. Moiraine was one herself. Once she knew what you had done, there was nothing for it but for her to begin teaching you. Did Moiraine never explain any of this to you?"

"nɛvɝ." ɛɡwin wɪʃt əɹ vɔɪs wɑz nɑt soʊ bɹɛθləs. "ʃi hæd . . . ʌðɝ mæɾɝz tə dil wɪð." nɪneɪiv snɔɹɾɪd sɔfli.

"Never." Egwene wished her voice was not so breathless. "She had . . . other matters to deal with." Nynaeve snorted softly.

"wɛl, mɔɪɹeɪn əz nɛvɝ bɪlivd ɪn tɛlɪŋ ɛniwʌn ɛniθɪŋ ðeɪ dɪd nɑt nid tə noʊ. noʊɪŋ sɝvz noʊ ɹil pɝpəs, bʌt ðɛn, niðɝ dʌz nɑt noʊɪŋ. maɪsɛlf, aɪ ɔlweɪz pɹəfɝ noʊɪŋ tə nɑt."

"Well, Moiraine has never believed in telling anyone anything they did not need to know. Knowing serves no real purpose, but then, neither does not knowing. Myself, I always prefer knowing to not."

"ɪz ðəɹ wʌn? ə pɪt, aɪ min?"

"Is there one? A pit, I mean?"

"ɑbviəsli nɑt soʊ fɑɹ," vɛɹɪn sɛd, tɪltɪŋ əɹ hɛd. "bʌt ðə nɛkst stɛp?" ʃi ʃɹʌɡd. "ju si, tʃaɪld, ðə mɔɹ jə tʃɹaɪ tə tʌtʃ ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs, ðə mɔɹ jə tʃɹaɪ tə tʃænəl ðə wʌn paʊɝ, ði iziɝ ɪt bɪkʌmz tə æktʃəli  də ɪt. jɛs, ɪn ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ, jə stʃɹɛtʃ aʊt tə ðə sɔɹs ən mɔɹ ɔfən ðən ɪts ɪz laɪk ɡɹæspɪŋ əɾ ɛɹ. əɹ jə æktʃəli  tʌtʃ seɪaɪdɑɹ, bʌɾ ivən wən jə fil ðə wʌn paʊɝ floʊɪŋ θɹu ju, jə faɪn jə kən də nʌθɪŋ wɪð ɪt. əɹ jə də sʌmθɪŋ, ən ɪɾ ɪzənt wʌt jə ɪntɛndəɾ əɾ ɔl. ðəɾ ɪz ðə deɪnʒɝ. juʒəwəli, wɪð ɡaɪɾəns ən tʃɹeɪnɪŋ - ən ðə ɡɝlz oʊn fɪɹ sloʊɪŋ əɹ daʊn - ði əbɪləɾi tə tʌtʃ ðə sɔɹs ən ði əbɪləɾi tə tʃænəl ðə paʊɝ kʌm təɡɛðɝ wɪð ði əbɪləɾi tə ʃiz ʃi ɪz duɪŋ. bʌt jə bɪɡæn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə tʃænəl wɪθaʊɾ ɛniwʌn ðəɹ tə titʃ jə ɛni kəntʃɹoʊl əɾ ɔl ʌv wʌt jə du. aɪ noʊ jə doʊn θɪŋk jəɹ vɛɹi fɑɹ əlɔŋ, ən jə ɑɹ nɑt, bʌt jə ɑɹ laɪk sʌmwʌn u hæz tɔt hɝsɛlf tə ɹʌn ʌp hɪlz - səmtaɪmz, ət list - wɪθaʊɾ ɛvɝ lɝnɪŋ haʊ tə ɹʌn daʊn ði ʌðɝ saɪd, əɹ tə wɔk. sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ jə ɑɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə fɔl, ɪf jə doʊn lɝn ðə ɹɛst ʌv aɪm aɪ æm nɑt tɔkɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɛniθɪŋ laɪk wʌt hæpənz wən wʌn ə ðoʊz pʊɹ mɛn bɪɡɪnz jəl jə wɪl nɑt ɡoʊ mæd; jə woʊn daɪ, nɑt wɪð sɪstɝz tə titʃ ən ɡaɪd jə - bʌt wʌt maɪt jə də ɪntaɪɝli baɪ æksəɾənt, nɛvɝ minɪŋ tə?" fəɹ ən ɪnstən ðə veɪɡnɪs hæd dʒɹɑp fɹəm vɛɹɪnz aɪz. fəɹ ən ɪnstənt, ɪt simd, ði ɛɛs sədaɪz ɡeɪz hæd flɪk fɹəm ɛɡwin tə nɪneɪiv əz ʃɑɹpli əz ði æmɪɝlɪnz hæd. "jɔɹ ɪneɪɾ əbɪləɾiz ɑɹ stʃɹɔŋ, ðəl ðeɪ wɪl ɡɹoʊ stʃɹɔŋɝ. jə mʌs lɝn tə kəntʃɹoʊl əm bɪfɔɹ jə hɑɹm jɝsɛlf, əɹ sʌmwʌn ɛls, əɹ ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni pipəl. ðəɾ ɪz wʌt mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə titʃ ju. ðəɾ əl aɪ wɪl tʃɹaɪ tə hɛlp jə wɪð tənaɪt, ən wʌɾ ə sɪstɝ wɪl hɛlp jə wɪð ɛvɹi naɪɾ əntɪl wi pʊt jə ɪndə ʃɛɹiəmz moʊst ʃiz ʃi ɪz mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz."

"Obviously not so far," Verin said, tilting her head. "But the next step?" She shrugged. "You see, child, the more you try to touch the True Source, the more you try to channel the One Power, the easier it becomes to actually do it. Yes, in the beginning, you stretch out to the Source and more often than not it is like grasping at air. Or you actually touch saidar, but even when you feel the One Power flowing through you, you find you can do nothing with it. Or you do something, and it isn't what you intended at all. That is the danger. Usually, with guidance and training - and the girl's own fear slowing her down - the ability to touch the Source and the ability to channel the Power come together with the ability to control what she is doing. But you began trying to channel without anyone there to teach you any control at all of what you do. I know you don't think you're very far along, and you are not, but you are like someone who has taught herself to run up hills - sometimes, at least - without ever learning how to run down the other side, or to walk. Sooner or later you are going to fall, if you don't learn the rest of it. Now, I am not talking about anything like what happens when one of those poor men begins channeling - you will not go mad; you won't die, not with sisters to teach and guide you - but what might you do entirely by accident, never meaning to?" For an instant the vagueness had dropped from Verin's eyes. For an instant, it seemed, the Aes Sedai's gaze had flicked from Egwene to Nynaeve as sharply as the Amyrlin's had. "Your innate abilities are strong, child, and they will grow stronger. You must learn to control them before you harm yourself, or someone else, or a great many people. That is what Moiraine was trying to teach you. That is what I will try to help you with tonight, and what a sister will help you with every night until we put you into Sheriam's most capable hands. She is Mistress of Novices."

ɛɡwin θɔt, kən ʃi noʊ əbaʊt ɹænd? ɪɾ ɪzən pɑsəbəl. ʃid nɛvɝ əv lɛɾ ɪm liv fæl dæɹə ɪf ʃi ivən səspɛktəd. bʌt ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ʃi hæd nɑɾ ɪmædʒənd wʌt ʃi sɔ. "θæŋk ju, vɛɹɪn sədaɪ. əl tʃɹaɪ."

Egwene thought, Can she know about Rand? It isn't possible. She'd never have let him leave Fal Dara if she even suspected. But she was sure she had not imagined what she saw. "Thank you, Verin Sedai. I will try."

nɪneɪiv ɹoʊz smuðli tə hɝ fit. "aɪ wɪl ɡoʊ sɪt baɪ ðə faɪɝ ən liv jə tu əloʊn."

Nynaeve rose smoothly to her feet. "I will go sit by the fire and leave you two alone."

"ju ʃəd steɪ," vɛɹɪn sɛd. "ju kəd pɹɑfət baɪ ɪt. fɹəm wʌt mɔɪɹeɪn əz toʊl mi, ɪt ʃəd teɪk oʊnli ə lɪɾəl tʃɹeɪnɪŋ fəɹ jə tə bi ɹeɪz tə ði æksɛptɪd."

"You should stay," Verin said. "You could profit by it. From what Moiraine has told me, it should take only a little training for you to be raised to the Accepted."

nɪneɪiv hɛzɪteɪɾɪd oʊnli ə moʊmən bɪfɔɹ ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛd fɝmli. "aɪ θæŋk jə fəɹ ði ɔfɝ, bʌɾ aɪ kən weɪɾ əntɪl wi ɹitʃ tɑɹ vəlɑn. ɛɡwin, ɪf jə nid mi, əl bi - "

Nynaeve hesitated only a moment before shaking her head firmly. "I thank you for the offer, but I can wait until we reach Tar Valon. Egwene, if you need me, I will be - "

"baɪ ɛni ɡeɪdʒ," vɛɹɪn kʌɾ ɪn, "ju ɑɹ ə wʊmən ɡɹoʊn, nɪneɪiv. juʒəwəli, ðə jʌŋɡɝ ə nɑvəs, ðə bɛɾɝ ʃi dʌz. nɑt wɪð ðə tʃɹeɪnɪŋ nɛsəsɛɹəli, bʌt kəz ə nɑvəs ɪz ɪkspɛktəd tə də əz ʃiz toʊld, wən ʃiz toʊld ən wɪθaʊt kwɛstʃən. ɪts ɹɪli oʊnli ʌv jus wʌns ði æktʃəwəl tʃɹeɪnɪŋ əz ɹitʃt ə sɝɾən pɔɪnt - ə hɛzəteɪʃən ɪn ðə ɹɔŋ pleɪs ðɛn, əɹ ə daʊɾ ʌv wʌt juv bɪn toʊl tə du, kən əv tʃɹædʒɪk kɑnsəkwɛnsəz - bʌɾ ɪts bɛɾɝ tə fɑloʊ ðə dɪsəplən ɔl ðə taɪm. ði æksɛptɪd, ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, ɑɹ ɪkspɛktəd tə kwɛstʃən θɪŋz, əz ɪts fɛl ðeɪ noʊ ɪnʌf tə noʊ wʌt kwɛstʃənz tə æsk ən wɛn. wɪtʃ dʒju θɪŋk jə wəd pɹəfɝ?"

"By any gauge," Verin cut in, "you are a woman grown, Nynaeve. Usually, the younger a novice, the better she does. Not with the training necessarily, but because a novice is expected to do as she is told, when she is told and without question. It is really only of use once the actual training has reached a certain point - a hesitation in the wrong place then, or a doubt of what you have been told to do, can have tragic consequences - but it is better to follow the discipline all the time. The Accepted, on the other hand, are expected to question things, as it is felt they know enough to know what questions to ask and when. Which do you think you would prefer?"

nɪneɪivz hænz taɪɾənd ɑn əɹ skɝt, ən ʃi lʊkt ət ðə tɛn flæp əɡɛn, fɹaʊnɪŋ. faɪnəli ʃi ɡeɪv ə ʃɔɹt nɑɾ ən sɛɾəld bæk daʊn ɑn ðə flɔɹ. "aɪ səpoʊz aɪ maɪɾ əz wɛl," ʃi sɛd.

Nynaeve's hands tightened on her skirt, and she looked at the tent flap again, frowning. Finally she gave a short nod and settled back down on the floor. "I suppose I might as well," she said.

"ɡʊd," vɛɹɪn sɛd. "naʊ. jə ɔlɹɛɾi noʊ ðɪs pɑɹt, ɛɡwin, bʌt fəɹ nɪneɪivz seɪk əl teɪk jə θɹu ɪt stɛp baɪ stɛp. ɪn taɪm, ɪɾəl bɪkʌm sɛkənd neɪtʃɝ - jəl də ɪɾ ɔl fæstɝ ðən jə kən θɪŋk ʌv ɪt - bʌt naʊ ɪts bɛs tə ɡoʊ sloʊli. kloʊs jəɹ aɪz, pliz. ɪt ɡoʊz bɛɾɝ ɪn ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ ɪf juv noʊ dɪstʃɹækʃənz əɾ ɔl." ɛɡwin kloʊzd əɹ aɪz. ðəɹ wɑz ə pɔz. "nɪneɪiv," vɛɹɪn sɛd, "pliz kloʊs jəɹ aɪz. ɪɾəl ɹɪli ɡoʊ bɛɾɝ." ənʌðɝ pɔz. "θæŋk ju, tʃaɪld. naʊ, jə mʌst ɛmpti jɝsɛlf. ɛmpti jəɹ θɔts. ðəɹ ɪz oʊnli wʌn θɪŋ ɪn jəɹ maɪnd. ðə bʌɾ ʌv ə flaʊɝ. oʊnli ðæt. oʊnli ðə bʌd. jə kən si ɪɾ ɪn ɛvɹi dɪteɪl. jə kən smɛl ɪt. jə kən fil ɪt. ɛvɹi veɪn ʌv ɛvɹi lif, ɛvɹi kɝv ʌv ɛvɹi pɛɾəl. jə kən fil ðə sæp pʌlsɪŋ. fil ɪt. noʊ ɪt. bi ɪt. jə ən ðə bʌɾ ɑɹ ðə seɪm. jə ɑɹ wʌn. jə ɑɹ ðə bʌd."

"Good," Verin said. "Now. You already know this part, Egwene, but for Nynaeve's sake I will take you through it step by step. In time, it will become second nature - you will do it all faster than you can think of it - but now it is best to go slowly. Close your eyes, please. It goes better in the beginning if you have no distractions at all." Egwene closed her eyes. There was a pause. "Nynaeve," Verin said, "please close your eyes. It will really go better." Another pause. "Thank you, child. Now, you must empty yourself. Empty your thoughts. There is only one thing in your mind. The bud of a flower. Only that. Only the bud. You can see it in every detail. You can smell it. You can feel it. Every vein of every leaf, every curve of every petal. You can feel the sap pulsing. Feel it. Know it. Be it. You and the bud are the same. You are one. You are the bud."

hɝ vɔɪs dʒɹoʊn ɑn hɪpnɑɾəkəli, bʌɾ ɛɡwin noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɹɪli hɝd; ʃi hæd dʌn ðɪs ɛksɝsaɪz bɪfɔɹ, wɪð mɔɪɹeɪn. ɪt wɑz sloʊ, bʌt mɔɪɹeɪn hæd sɛɾ ɪt wəd kʌm mɔɹ kwɪkli wɪð pɹæktəs. ɪnsaɪd hɝsɛlf, ʃi wɑz ə ɹoʊzbʌd, ɹɛd pɛɾəlz kɝl taɪtli. jɛt sʌɾənli ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɛls. laɪt. laɪt pɹɛsɪŋ ɑn ðə pɛɾəlz. sloʊli ðə pɛɾəlz ənfoʊldəd, tɝnɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə laɪt, əbzɔɹbɪŋ ðə laɪt. ðə ɹoʊz ən ðə laɪt wɝ wʌn. ɛɡwin ən ðə laɪt wɝ wʌn. ʃi kəd fil ðə mɛɹəs tʃɹɪkəl ʌv ɪt sipɪŋ θɹu hɝ. ʃi stʃɹɛtʃt fəɹ mɔɹ, stʃɹeɪn fəɹ mɔɹ. . . .

Her voice droned on hypnotically, but Egwene no longer really heard; she had done this exercise before, with Moiraine. It was slow, but Moiraine had said it would come more quickly with practice. Inside herself, she was a rosebud, red petals curled tightly. Yet suddenly there was something else. Light. Light pressing on the petals. Slowly the petals unfolded, turning toward the light, absorbing the light. The rose and the light were one. Egwene and the light were one. She could feel the merest trickle of it seeping through her. She stretched for more, strained for more. . . .

ɪn ən ɪnstən ɪt wɑz ɔl ɡɔn, ɹoʊz ən laɪt. mɔɪɹeɪn hæɾ ɔlsoʊ sɛɾ ɪt kəd nɑt bi fɔɹst. wɪð ə saɪ, ʃi oʊpən əɹ aɪz. nɪneɪiv hæɾ ə ɡɹɪm lʊk ɑn əɹ feɪs. vɛɹɪn wɑz əz kɑm əz ɛvɝ.

In an instant it was all gone, rose and light. Moiraine had also said it could not be forced. With a sigh, she opened her eyes. Nynaeve had a grim look on her face. Verin was as calm as ever.

"ju kænɑt meɪk ɪt hæpən," ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑz seɪɪŋ. "ju mʌs lɛɾ ɪt hæpən. jə mʌst sɝɛndɝ tə ðə paʊɝ bɪfɔɹ jə kən kəntʃɹoʊl ɪt."

"You cannot make it happen," the Aes Sedai was saying. "You must let it happen. You must surrender to the Power before you can control it."

"ðɪs ɪz kəmplit fulɪʃnəs," nɪneɪiv mʌɾɝd. "aɪ doʊn fil laɪk ə flaʊɝ. ɪf ɛniθɪŋ, aɪ fil laɪk ə blækθɝn bʊʃ. aɪ θɪŋk əl weɪt baɪ ðə faɪɝ æftɝ ɔl."

"This is complete foolishness," Nynaeve muttered. "I don't feel like a flower. If anything, I feel like a blackthorn bush. I think I will wait by the fire after all."

"æz jə wɪʃ," vɛɹɪn sɛd. "dɪɾ aɪ mɛnʃən ðət nɑvəsɪz də tʃɔɹz? ðeɪ wɑʃ dɪʃəz, skɹʌb flɔɹz, də lɔnʒɹi, sɝv ət teɪbəl, ɔl sɔɹts ə θɪŋz. aɪ maɪsɛlf θɪŋk ðə sɝvəns də ə bɛɾɝ dʒɑb ʌv ɪt baɪ fɑɹ, bʌɾ ɪts dʒɛnɝəli fɛl ðət sətʃ leɪbɝ bɪlz kɛɹɪktɝ. oʊ, jə ɑɹ steɪɪŋ? ɡʊd. wɛl, tʃaɪld, ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðəɾ ivən ə blækθɝn bʊʃ əz flaʊɝz səmtaɪmz, bjuɾəfəl ən waɪɾ əmʌŋ ðə θɔɹnz. wɪl tʃɹaɪ ɪt wʌn əɾ ə taɪm. naʊ, fɹəm ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ, ɛɡwin. kloʊs jəɹ aɪz."

"As you wish," Verin said. "Did I mention that novices do chores? They wash dishes, scrub floors, do laundry, serve at table, all sorts of things. I myself think the servants do a better job of it by far, but it is generally felt that such labor builds character. Oh, you are staying? Good. Well, child, remember that even a blackthorn bush has flowers sometimes, beautiful and white among the thorns. We will try it one at a time. Now, from the beginning, Egwene. Close your eyes."

sɛvɹəl taɪmz bɪfɔɹ vɛɹɪn lɛft, ɛɡwin fɛl ðə floʊ ʌv ðə paʊɝ θɹu hɝ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɛvɝ vɛɹi stʃɹɔŋ, ən ðə moʊst ʃi mænədʒd wɪð ɪt wɑz tə pɹədus ə stɝ ɪn ði ɛɹ ðət meɪd ðə tɛn flæp stɝ slaɪtli. ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ə sniz cʊɾə dʌn əz mʌtʃ. ʃi hæd dʌn bɛɾɝ wɪð mɔɪɹeɪn; səmtaɪmz, ət list. ʃi wɪʃt ɪt wɑz mɔɪɹeɪn duɪŋ ðə titʃɪŋ.

Several times before Verin left, Egwene felt the flow of the Power through her, but it was never very strong, and the most she managed with it was to produce a stir in the air that made the tent flap stir slightly. She was sure a sneeze could have done as much. She had done better with Moiraine; sometimes, at least. She wished it was Moiraine doing the teaching.

nɪneɪiv nɛvɝ ivən fɛlt ə ɡlɪmɝ, əɹ soʊ ʃi sɛd. baɪ ði ɛn əɹ aɪz wɝ sɛɾ ən əɹ maʊθ soʊ taɪt ðəɾ ɛɡwin wɑz əfɹeɪd ʃi wɑz əbaʊt tə bɪɡɪn bɪɹeɪɾɪŋ vɛɹɪn əz ɪf ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ ə vɪlədʒ wʊmən ɪntʃɹuɾɪŋ ɑn əɹ pɹaɪvəsi. bʌt vɛɹɪn sɪmpli toʊld əɹ tə kloʊz əɹ aɪz wʌns əɡɛn, ðɪs taɪm wɪθaʊɾ ɛɡwin.

Nynaeve never even felt a glimmer, or so she said. By the end her eyes were set and her mouth so tight that Egwene was afraid she was about to begin berating Verin as if the Aes Sedai were a village woman intruding on her privacy. But Verin simply told her to close her eyes once again, this time without Egwene.

ɛɡwin wɑz sɪɾɪŋ, wɑtʃɪŋ ði ʌðɝ tu bɪtwin əɹ jɔnz. ðə naɪt hæd ɡɹoʊn leɪt, wɛl pæs ðə taɪm ʃi wəd juʒəwəli bi əslip. nɪneɪiv wɔɹ ə feɪs laɪk wik-oʊl dɛθ, hɝ aɪz klæmpt ʃʌɾ əz ɪf ʃi nɛvɝ mɛn tə oʊpən əm ən əɹ hænz waɪt-nʌkəl fɪsts ɪn əɹ læp. ɛɡwin hoʊp ðə wɪzdəmz tɛmpɝ dɪd nɑt bɹeɪk lus, nɑɾ æftɝ ʃi hæd hɛld ɪt ðɪs lɔŋ.

Egwene was sitting, watching the other two between her yawns. The night had grown late, well past the time she would usually be asleep. Nynaeve wore a face like week-old death, her eyes clamped shut as if she never meant to open them and her hands white-knuckled fists in her lap. Egwene hoped the Wisdom's temper did not break loose, not after she had held it this long.

"fil ðə floʊ θɹu ju," vɛɹɪn wɑz seɪɪŋ. hɝ vɔɪs dɪd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ, bʌt sʌɾənli ðəɹ wɑz ə ɡlim ɪn əɹ aɪz. "fil ðə floʊ. floʊ ʌv ðə paʊɝ. floʊ laɪk ə bɹiz, ə dʒɛntəl stɝɪŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ." ɛɡwin sæɾ ʌp stʃɹeɪt. ðɪs wɑz haʊ vɛɹɪn hæd ɡaɪɾəd əɹ itʃ taɪm ʃi hæɾ æktʃəli  hæd ðə paʊɝ floʊɪŋ θɹu hɝ. "ə sɑf bɹiz, ðə slaɪɾəst muvmən ʌv ɛɹ. sɑft."

"Feel the flow through you," Verin was saying. Her voice did not change, but suddenly there was a gleam in her eyes. "Feel the flow. Flow of the Power. Flow like a breeze, a gentle stirring in the air." Egwene sat up straight. This was how Verin had guided her each time she had actually had the Power flowing through her. "A soft breeze, the slightest movement of air. Soft."

əbɹʌpli ðə stæk blæŋkəts bɝst ɪndə fleɪm laɪk fætwʊd.

Abruptly the stacked blankets burst into flame like fatwood.

nɪneɪiv oʊpən əɹ aɪz wɪð ə jɛl. ɛɡwin wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ɪf ʃi skɹimd əɹ nɑt. ɔl ɛɡwin nu wɑz ðət ʃi wɑz ɑn əɹ fit, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kɪk ðə bɝnɪŋ blæŋkəts aʊtsaɪd bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ sɛt ðə tɛn ɑn faɪɝ. bɪfɔɹ ʃi mænədʒd ə sɛkən kɪk, ðə fleɪmz vænɪʃt, livɪŋ wɪspi smoʊk ɹaɪzɪŋ fɹəm ə tʃɑɹd mæs ən ðə smɛl ə bɝnd wʊl.

Nynaeve opened her eyes with a yell. Egwene was not sure if she screamed or not. All Egwene knew was that she was on her feet, trying to kick the burning blankets outside before they set the tent on fire. Before she managed a second kick, the flames vanished, leaving wispy smoke rising from a charred mass and the smell of burned wool.

"wɛl," vɛɹɪn sɛd. "wɛl. aɪ dɪd nɑɾ ɪkspɛk tə hæv tə daʊs ə faɪɝ. doʊn feɪn ɑn mi, tʃaɪld. ɪts ɔl ɹaɪt naʊ. aɪ tʊk kɛɹ ʌv ɪt."

"Well," Verin said. "Well. I did not expect to have to douse a fire. Don't faint on me, child. It's all right now. I took care of it."

"aɪ - aɪ wɑz æŋɡɹi." nɪneɪiv spoʊk θɹu tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ lɪps ɪn ə blʌdləs feɪs. "aɪ hɝd jə tɔkɪŋ əbaʊɾ ə bɹiz, tɛlɪŋ mi wʌt tə du, ən faɪɝ dʒʌs pɑpt ɪndə maɪ hɛd. aɪ - aɪ dɪdn min tə bɝn ɛniθɪŋ. ɪt wɑz dʒʌst ə smɔl faɪɝ, ɪn - ɪn maɪ hɛd." ʃi ʃʌɾɝəd.

"I - I was angry." Nynaeve spoke through trembling lips in a bloodless face. "I heard you talking about a breeze, telling me what to do, and fire just popped into my head. I - I didn't mean to burn anything. It was just a small fire, in - in my head." She shuddered.

"aɪ səpoʊz ɪt wɑz ə smɔl faɪɝ, ət ðæt." vɛɹɪn bɑɹkt ə læf ðət wɑz ɡɔn wɪð ənʌðɝ lʊk ət nɪneɪivz feɪs. "ɑɹ jə ɔl ɹaɪt, tʃaɪld? ɪf jə fil ɪl, aɪ kæn. . . ." nɪneɪiv ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, ən vɛɹɪn nɑɾəd. "ɹɛst ɪz wʌt jə nid. boʊθ ə ju. aɪv wɝk jə tu hɑɹd. jə mʌst ɹɛst. ði æmɪɝlɪn wɪl əv əs ɔl ʌp ən əweɪ bɪfɔɹ fɝs laɪt." stændɪŋ, ʃi toʊd ðə tʃɑɹd blæŋkəts. "aɪ wɪl əv səm mɔɹ blæŋkəts bɹɔt tə ju. aɪ hoʊp ðɪs ʃoʊz boʊθ ə jə haʊ ɪmpɔɹɾənt kəntʃɹoʊl ɪz. jə mʌs lɝn tə də wʌt jə min tə du, ən nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ. əsaɪd fɹəm hɑɹmɪŋ sʌmwʌn ɛls, ɪf jə dʒɹɔ mɔɹ ə ðə paʊɝ ðən jə kən seɪfli hændəl - ən jə kænɑt hændəl mʌtʃ, jɛt; bʌɾ ɪɾəl ɡɹoʊ - ɪf jə dʒɹɔ tu mʌtʃ, jə kən dɪstʃɹɔɪ jɝsɛlf. jə kən daɪ. əɹ jə kən bɝn jɝsɛlf aʊt, dɪstʃɹɔɪ wʌɾ əbɪləɾi jə hæv." əz ɪf ʃi hæd nɑt toʊld əm ðeɪ wɝ wɔkɪŋ ə naɪf ɛdʒ, ʃi æɾəd ə tʃɪɹfəl "slip wɛl." wɪð ðæt, ʃi wɑz ɡɔn.

"I suppose it was a small fire, at that." Verin barked a laugh that was gone with another look at Nynaeve's face. "Are you all right, child? If you feel ill, I can. . . ." Nynaeve shook her head, and Verin nodded. "Rest is what you need. Both of you. I've worked you too hard. You must rest. The Amyrlin will have us all up and away before first light." Standing, she toed the charred blankets. "I will have some more blankets brought to you. I hope this shows both of you how important control is. You must learn to do what you mean to do, and nothing more. Aside from harming someone else, if you draw more of the Power than you can safely handle - and you cannot handle much, yet; but it will grow - if you draw too much, you can destroy yourself. You can die. Or you can burn yourself out, destroy what ability you have." As if she had not told them they were walking a knife edge, she added a cheerful "Sleep well." With that, she was gone.

ɛɡwin pʊɾ əɹ ɑɹmz ɝaʊnd nɪneɪiv ən hʌɡd əɹ taɪt. "ɪɾ ɪz ɔl ɹaɪt, nɪneɪiv. ðəɹ ɪz noʊ nid tə bi fɹaɪɾənd. wʌns jə lɝn tə kəntʃɹoʊl - "

Egwene put her arms around Nynaeve and hugged her tight. "It is all right, Nynaeve. There is no need to be frightened. Once you learn to control - "

nɪneɪiv ɡeɪv ə kɹoʊkɪŋ læf. "aɪ æm nɑt fɹaɪɾənd." ʃi ɡlænst saɪdweɪz ət ðə smoʊkɪŋ blæŋkəts ən twɪtʃt əɹ aɪz əweɪ. "ɪt teɪks mɔɹ ðən ə lɪɾəl faɪɝ tə fɹaɪɾən mi." bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt lʊk ət ðə blæŋkəts əɡɛn, ivən wən ə wɔɹɾɝ keɪm tə teɪk əm əweɪ ən liv nu.

Nynaeve gave a croaking laugh. "I am not frightened." She glanced sideways at the smoking blankets and twitched her eyes away. "It takes more than a little fire to frighten me." But she did not look at the blankets again, even when a Warder came to take them away and leave new.

vɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt kʌm əɡɛn, əz ʃi hæd sɛd ʃi wəd nɑt. ɪndid, əz ðeɪ dʒɝniɾ ɑn, saʊθ ən wɛst, deɪ baɪ deɪ, əz fæst əz ðə fʊtmən kəd muv, vɛɹɪn peɪd ðə tu wɪmən fɹəm ɛmənz fil noʊ mɔɹ maɪn ðən mɔɪɹeɪn dɪd, ðən dɪɾ ɛni ʌv ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðeɪ wɝ nɑt pɹɪsaɪsli ənfɹɛnli, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌt ɹæðɝ dɪstən ən əluf, əz ɪf pɹiɑkjəpaɪd. ðɛɹ kulnəs haɪɾənd ɛɡwinz əniz, ən bɹɔt bæk ɔl ðə teɪlz ʃi hæd hɝɾ əz ə tʃaɪld.

Verin did not come again, as she had said she would not. Indeed, as they journeyed on, south and west, day by day, as fast as the footmen could move, Verin paid the two women from Emond's Field no more mind than Moiraine did, than did any of the Aes Sedai. They were not precisely unfriendly, the Aes Sedai, but rather distant and aloof, as if preoccupied. Their coolness heightened Egwene's unease, and brought back all the tales she had heard as a child.

hɝ mʌðɝ hæɾ ɔlweɪz toʊld əɹ ðə teɪlz əbaʊɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ ə lɑɾ ə ful mɛnz nɑnsɛns, bʌt niðɝ əɹ mʌðɝ nɔɹ ɛni ʌðɝ wʊmən ɪn ɛmənz fil hæɾ ɛvɝ mɛɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ bɪfɔɹ mɔɪɹeɪn keɪm ðɛɹ. ʃi hɝsɛlf hæd spɛn ə ɡʊd dil ə taɪm wɪð mɔɪɹeɪn, ən mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz pɹuf tə hɝ ðət nɑɾ ɔl ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ laɪk ðə teɪlz. koʊl mənɪpjəleɪɾɝz ən mɝsələs dɪstʃɹɔɪɝz. bɹeɪkɝz ə ðə wɝld. ʃi nu naʊ ðət ðoʊz, ət list - ðə bɹeɪkɝz ə ðə wɝld - hæd bɪn meɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ, wən ðəɹ wɝ sʌtʃ, ɪn ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz, bʌɾ ɪt dɪd nɑt hɛlp ə ɡɹeɪt dil. nɑɾ ɔl ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ laɪk ðə teɪlz, bʌt haʊ mɛni, ən wɪtʃ?

Her mother had always told her the tales about Aes Sedai were a lot of fool men's nonsense, but neither her mother nor any other woman in Emond's Field had ever met an Aes Sedai before Moiraine came there. She herself had spent a good deal of time with Moiraine, and Moiraine was proof to her that not all Aes Sedai were like the tales. Cold manipulators and merciless destroyers. Breakers of the World. She knew now that those, at least - the Breakers of the World - had been male Aes Sedai, when there were such, in the Age of Legends, but it did not help a great deal. Not all Aes Sedai were like the tales, but how many, and which?

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hu keɪm tə ðə tɛn itʃ naɪt wɝ soʊ mɪks ðət ðeɪ dɪd nɑt hɛlp əɾ ɔl ɪn klɪɹɪŋ əɹ θɔts. ɑlviɛɝɪn wɑz əz kul ən bɪznɪslaɪk əz ə mɝtʃən kʌm tə baɪ wʊl ən təbæk, sɝpɹaɪz ðət nɪneɪiv wɑz pɑɹɾ ə ðə lɛsən bʌɾ æksɛptɪŋ, ʃɑɹp ɪn əɹ kɹɪɾɪsɪzəmz bʌɾ ɔlweɪz ɹɛɾi tə tʃɹaɪ əɡɛn. ɑlɑnə mɑsvɑni læft ən spɛn əz mʌtʃ taɪm tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt ðə wɝld, ən mɛn, əz ʃi dɪd titʃɪŋ. ɑlɑnə ʃoʊd tu mʌtʃ ɪntʃɹəst ɪn ɹænd ən pɛɹɪn ən mæt fəɹ ɛɡwinz kʌmfɝt, ðoʊ. ɪspɛʃli ɹænd. wɝst ʌv ɔl wɑz liɑnʒɹɪn, ði oʊnli wʌn u wɔɹ əɹ ʃɔl; ði ʌðɝz hæɾ ɔl pækt əm əweɪ bɪfɔɹ livɪŋ fæl dæɹə. liɑnʒɹɪn sæt fɪŋɡɝɪŋ əɹ ɹɛd fɹɪnʒ ən tɔt lɪɾəl, ən ɹɪlʌktənli ət ðæt. ʃi kwɛstʃən ɛɡwin ən nɪneɪiv əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd bɪn əkjuzd ʌv ə kɹaɪm, ən əɹ kwɛstʃənz wɝ ɔl əbaʊt ðə θɹi bɔɪz. ʃi kɛpt ɪɾ ʌp əntɪl nɪneɪiv θɹu hɝ aʊt - ɛɡwin wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ waɪ nɪneɪiv dɪd soʊ - ən ðən ʃi lɛft wɪð ə wɔɹnɪŋ.

The Aes Sedai who came to the tent each night were so mixed that they did not help at all in clearing her thoughts. Alviarin was as cool and businesslike as a merchant come to buy wool and tabac, surprised that Nynaeve was part of the lesson but accepting, sharp in her criticisms but always ready to try again. Alanna Mosvani laughed and spent as much time talking about the world, and men, as she did teaching. Alanna showed too much interest in Rand and Perrin and Mat for Egwene's comfort, though. Especially Rand. Worst of all was Liandrin, the only one who wore her shawl; the others had all packed them away before leaving Fal Dara. Liandrin sat fingering her red fringe and taught little, and reluctantly at that. She questioned Egwene and Nynaeve as if they had been accused of a crime, and her questions were all about the three boys. She kept it up until Nynaeve threw her out - Egwene was not sure why Nynaeve did so - and then she left with a warning.

"wɑtʃ jʊɹsɛlvz, maɪ dɔɾɝz. jə ɑɹ ɪn jəɹ vɪlədʒ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ. naʊ jə dæbəl jəɹ toʊz wɛɹ ðəɹ ɑɹ θɪŋz tə baɪt ju."

"Watch yourselves, my daughters. You are in your village no longer. Now you dabble your toes where there are things to bite you."

faɪnəli ðə kɑləm ɹitʃt ðə vɪlədʒ ə mɛɾoʊ, ɑn ðə bæŋks ə ðə mɔɹə, wɪtʃ ɹæn əlɔŋ ðə bɔɹɾɝ bɪtwin ʃaɪnɝ ən ɝæfəl ən soʊ ɪndə ðə ɹɪvɝ ɛɹɪnɪn.

Finally the column reached the village of Medo, on the banks of the Mora, which ran along the border between Shienar and Arafel and so into the River Erinin.

ɛɡwin wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz ði ɛɛs sədaɪz kwɛstʃənz əbaʊt ɹænd ðət hæd meɪɾ əɹ stɑɹt dʒɹimɪŋ ə hɪm, ðəɾ ən wɝiɪŋ əbaʊt hɪm, əbaʊt wɛðɝ i ən ði ʌðɝz hæd hæd tə fɑloʊ ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ ɪndə ðə blaɪt. ðə dʒɹimz wɝ ɔlweɪz bæd, bʌɾ ət fɝs ðeɪ wɝ dʒʌs ði ɔɹɾənɛɹi sɔɹɾ ə naɪtmɛɹ. baɪ ðə naɪt ðeɪ ɹitʃt mɛɾoʊ, ðə dʒɹimz hæd tʃeɪnʒd, ðoʊ.

Egwene was sure it was the Aes Sedai's questions about Rand that had made her start dreaming of him, that and worrying about him, about whether he and the others had had to follow the Horn of Valere into the Blight. The dreams were always bad, but at first they were just the ordinary sort of nightmare. By the night they reached Medo, the dreams had changed, though.
