"pɑɹɾən, ɛɛs sədaɪ," ɛɡwin æsk dɪfəɾəntli, "bʌɾ əv jə sin mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ?" ðə slɛndɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ weɪvd əɹ əweɪ ən hɝiɾ ɑn daʊn ðə kɹaʊɾəd, tɔɹtʃ-lɪt vɪlədʒ stʃɹit, kɔlɪŋ fəɹ sʌmwʌn tə bi kɛɹfəl wɪð əɹ hɔɹs. ðə wʊmən wɑz ə ðə jɛloʊ ədʒɑ, ðoʊ nɑt wɛɹɪŋ əɹ ʃɔl naʊ; ɛɡwin nu noʊ mɔɹ ə hɝ ðən ðæt, nɑɾ ivən əɹ neɪm.

"Pardon, Aes Sedai," Egwene asked diffidently, "but have you seen Moiraine Sedai?" The slender Aes Sedai waved her away and hurried on down the crowded, torch-lit village street, calling for someone to be careful with her horse. The woman was of the Yellow Ajah, though not wearing her shawl now; Egwene knew no more of her than that, not even her name.

mɛɾoʊ wɑz ə smɔl vɪlədʒ - ðoʊ ɛɡwin wɑz ʃɑk tə ɹilaɪz ðət wʌt ʃi naʊ θɔɾ ʌv əz ə "smɔl vɪlədʒ" wɑz əz bɪɡ əz ɛmənz fild - ən ɪt wɑz oʊvɝwɛlm naʊ wɪð mɛni mɔɹ aʊtsaɪɾɝz ðən ðəɹ wɝ ɪnhæbəɾənts. hɔɹsəz ən pipəl fɪl ðə nɛɹoʊ stʃɹits, dʒɑsəlɪŋ tə ðə dɑks pæs vɪlɪdʒɝz u nɛlt wɛnɛvɝ ən ənsiɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ spɛd baɪ. hɑɹʃ tɔɹtʃlaɪt lɪɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ. ðə tu dɑks dʒʌɾɪd aʊɾ ɪndə ðə ɹɪvɝ mɔɹə laɪk stoʊn fɪŋɡɝz, ən itʃ hoʊstɪɾ ə pɛɹ ə smɔl, tu-mæstəd ʃɪps. ðɛɹ, hɔɹsəz wɝ biɪŋ hɔɪstəɾ ɑn bɔɹd baɪ bumz ən keɪbəlz ən kænvəs kɹeɪɾəlz ʌndɝ ðɛɹ bɛliz. mɔɹ ə ðə ʃɪps - haɪ-saɪɾəd ən staʊt, wɪð læntɝnz tɑpɪŋ ðɛɹ mæsts - kɹaʊɾəd ðə mun-stʃɹikt ɹɪvɝ, ɔlɹɛɾi loʊɾəd əɹ weɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ tɝn. ɹoʊboʊts fɛɹiɾ aʊɾ ɑɹtʃɝz ən pɪkmɛn, ðə ɹeɪz paɪks meɪkɪŋ ðə boʊts lʊk laɪk dʒaɪɡæntɪk pɹɪkəlbæks swɪmɪŋ ɑn ðə sɝfəs.

Medo was a small village - though Egwene was shocked to realize that what she now thought of as a "small village" was as big as Emond's Field - and it was overwhelmed now with many more outsiders than there were inhabitants. Horses and people filled the narrow streets, jostling to the docks past villagers who knelt whenever an unseeing Aes Sedai sped by. Harsh torchlight lit everything. The two docks jutted out into the River Mora like stone fingers, and each hosted a pair of small, two-masted ships. There, horses were being hoisted on board by booms and cables and canvas cradles under their bellies. More of the ships - high-sided and stout, with lanterns topping their masts - crowded the moon-streaked river, already loaded or waiting their turn. Rowboats ferried out archers and pikemen, the raised pikes making the boats look like gigantic pricklebacks swimming on the surface.

ɑn ðə lɛft-hæn dɑk ɛɡwin faʊn æneɪjə, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə loʊɾɪŋ ən tʃɪviɪŋ ðoʊz u wɝ nɑt muvɪŋ fæst ɪnʌf. ðoʊ ʃi hæd nɛvɝ sɛd mɔɹ ðən tu wɝdz tə ɛɡwin, æneɪjə sim dɪfɹən fɹəm ði ʌðɝz, mɔɹ laɪk ə wʊmən fɹəm hoʊm. ɛɡwin kəd pɪktʃɝ əɹ beɪkɪŋ ɪn əɹ kɪtʃən; ʃi kəd nɑt si ɛni ʌv ði ʌðɝz soʊ. "æneɪjə sədaɪ, hæv jə sin mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ? aɪ nid tə tɔk tə hɝ."

On the left-hand dock Egwene found Anaiya, watching the loading and chivying those who were not moving fast enough. Though she had never said more than two words to Egwene, Anaiya seemed different from the others, more like a woman from home. Egwene could picture her baking in her kitchen; she could not see any of the others so. "Anaiya Sedai, have you seen Moiraine Sedai? I need to talk to her."

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ lʊkt ɝaʊnd wɪð ən æbsən fɹaʊn. "wʌt? oʊ, ɪts ju, tʃaɪld. mɔɪɹeɪn ɪz ɡɔn. ən jəɹ fɹɛnd, nɪneɪiv, ɪz ɔlɹɛɾi aʊɾ ɑn ðə ɹɪvɝ kwin. aɪ hæd tə bʌndəl əɹ ɑntu ə boʊt maɪsɛlf, ʃaʊɾɪŋ ðət ʃi wəd nɑt ɡoʊ wɪθaʊt ju. laɪt, wʌɾ ə skɹæmbəl! jə ʃəd bi əbɔɹd, jɝsɛlf. faɪn ə boʊt ɡoʊɪŋ aʊt tə ðə ɹɪvɝ kwin. jə tu wɪl bi tʃɹævlɪŋ wɪð ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, soʊ maɪn jɝsɛlf wʌns jəɹ ɑn bɔɹd. noʊ sinz əɹ tæntʃɹəmz."

The Aes Sedai looked around with an absent frown. "What? Oh, it's you, child. Moiraine is gone. And your friend, Nynaeve, is already out on the River Queen. I had to bundle her onto a boat myself, shouting that she would not go without you. Light, what a scramble! You should be aboard, yourself. Find a boat going out to the River Queen. You two will be traveling with the Amyrlin Seat, so mind yourself once you're on board. No scenes or tantrums."

"wɪtʃ ʃɪp ɪz mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪz?"

"Which ship is Moiraine Sedai's?"

"mɔɪɹeɪn ɪzən ɑn ə ʃɪp, ɡɝl. ʃiz ɡɔn, tu deɪz ɡɔn, ən ði æmɪɝlɪn ɪz ɪn ə teɪkɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪt." æneɪjə ɡɹɪməst ən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, ðoʊ moʊst ə hɝ ətɛnʃən wɑz stɪl ɑn ðə wɝkɝz. "fɝs mɔɪɹeɪn vænɪʃɪz wɪð læn, ðən liɑnʒɹɪn ɹaɪɾ ɑn mɔɪɹeɪnz hilz, ən ðən vɛɹɪn, nʌn ə ðɛm wɪð soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə wɝd fəɹ ɛniwʌn. vɛɹɪn dɪd nɑɾ ivən teɪk əɹ wɔɹɾɝ; toʊmɑs ɪz tʃuɪŋ neɪlz wɪð wɝi oʊvɝ hɝ." ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɡlænst ət ðə skaɪ. ðə wæksɪŋ mun ʃoʊn wɪθaʊt ðə hɪnʒɹəns ə klaʊdz. "wi wɪl əv tə kɔl ðə wɪn əɡɛn, ən ði æmɪɝlɪn wɪl nɑt bi plizd wɪð ðæt, iðɝ. ʃi sɛz ʃi wɑns əs ɑn əɹ weɪ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn wɪðɪn ən aʊɝ, ən ʃɪl bɹʊk noʊ dɪleɪz. aɪ wəd nɑt wɑnə bi mɔɪɹeɪn, əɹ liɑnʒɹɪn, əɹ vɛɹɪn, wən ʃi siz əm nɛkst. ðəl wɪʃ ðeɪ wɝ nɑvəsɪz əɡɛn. waɪ, tʃaɪld, wʌts ðə mæɾɝ?"

"Moiraine isn't on a ship, girl. She's gone, two days gone, and the Amyrlin is in a taking over it." Anaiya grimaced and shook her head, though most of her attention was still on the workers. "First Moiraine vanishes with Lan, then Liandrin right on Moiraine's heels, and then Verin, none of them with so much as a word for anyone. Verin did not even take her Warder; Tomas is chewing nails with worry over her." The Aes Sedai glanced at the sky. The waxing moon shone without the hindrance of clouds. "We will have to call the wind again, and the Amyrlin will not be pleased with that, either. She says she wants us on our way to Tar Valon within an hour, and she will brook no delays. I would not want to be Moiraine, or Liandrin, or Verin, when she sees them next. They'll wish they were novices again. Why, child, what's the matter?"

ɛɡwin dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ. mɔɪɹeɪn ɡɔn? ʃi kæn bi! aɪ hæv tə tɛl sʌmbɑɾi, sʌmbɑɾi hu woʊn læf ət mi. ʃi ɪmædʒən æneɪjə bæk ɪn ɛmənz fild, lɪsnɪŋ tə hɝ dɔɾɝz pɹɑbləmz; ðə wʊmən fɪt ðə pɪktʃɝ. "æneɪjə sədaɪ, ɹænd ɪz ɪn tʃɹʌbəl."

Egwene drew a deep breath. Moiraine gone? She can't be! I have to tell somebody, somebody who won't laugh at me. She imagined Anaiya back in Emond's Field, listening to her daughter's problems; the woman fit the picture. "Anaiya Sedai, Rand is in trouble."

æneɪjə ɡeɪv əɹ ə kənsɪɾɝɪŋ lʊk. "ðæt tɔl bɔɪ fɹəm jəɹ vɪlədʒ? mɪsɪŋ ɪm ɔlɹɛɾi, ɑɹ ju? wɛl, aɪ ʃʊdn bi sɝpɹaɪzd ɪf hiz ɪn tʃɹʌbəl. jʌŋ mɛn ɪz eɪdʒ juʒəwəli ɑɹ. ðoʊ ɪt wɑz ði ʌðɝ wʌn - mæt? - hu hæd ðə lʊk ə tʃɹʌbəl. vɛɹi wɛl, tʃaɪld. aɪ doʊn min tə mɑk jə əɹ meɪk laɪt. wʌt kaɪndə tʃɹʌbəl, ən haʊ dʒju noʊ? hi ən lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹ mʌst əv ðə hɔɹn ən bi bæk ɪn fæl dæɹə baɪ naʊ. əɹ ɛls ðeɪv hæd tə fɑloʊ ɪɾ ɪndə ðə blaɪt, ən ðɛɹz nʌθɪŋ tə də əbaʊt ðæt."

Anaiya gave her a considering look. "That tall boy from your village? Missing him already, are you? Well, I shouldn't be surprised if he is in trouble. Young men his age usually are. Though it was the other one - Mat? - who had the look of trouble. Very well, child. I don't mean to mock you or make light. What kind of trouble, and how do you know? He and Lord Ingtar must have the Horn and be back in Fal Dara by now. Or else they've had to follow it into the Blight, and there's nothing to do about that."

"aɪ - aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðəɹ ɪn ðə blaɪt, əɹ bæk ɪn fæl dæɹə. aɪ hæɾ ə dʒɹim." ʃi sɛɾ ɪt hæf dɪfaɪənli. ɪt saʊndəd sɪli wən ʃi sɛɾ ɪt, bʌɾ ɪt hæd sim soʊ ɹil. ə naɪtmɛɹ fəɹ tʃɹu, bʌt ɹil. fɝs ðəɹ hæd bɪn ə mæn wɪð ə mæsk oʊvɝ ɪz feɪs, ən faɪɝ ɪn pleɪs ə hɪz aɪz. dɪspaɪt ðə mæsk, ʃi hæd θɔɾ i wɑz sɝpɹaɪz tə si hɝ. hɪz lʊk hæd fɹaɪɾənd əɹ tɪl ʃi θɔɾ əɹ boʊnz wəd bɹeɪk fɹəm ʃɪvɝɪŋ, bʌt sʌɾənli hi vænɪʃt, ən ʃi sɔ ɹænd slipɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ɹæpt ɪn ə kloʊk. ə wʊmən hæd bɪn stændɪŋ oʊvɝ hɪm, lʊkɪŋ daʊn. hɝ feɪs wɑz ɪn ʃædoʊ, bʌɾ əɹ aɪz sim tə ʃaɪn laɪk ðə mun, ən ɛɡwin hæd noʊn ʃi wɑz ivəl. ðən ðəɹ wɑz ə flæʃ ə laɪt, ən ðeɪ wɝ ɡɔn. boʊθ ə ðɛm. ən bɪhaɪn ɪɾ ɔl, ɔlmoʊs laɪk ənʌðɝ θɪŋ ɔltəɡɛðɝ, wɑz ðə fil ə deɪnʒɝ, əz ɪf ə tʃɹæp wɑz dʒʌs bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə snæp ʃʌɾ ɑn ən ʌnsəspɛktɪŋ læm, ə tʃɹæp wɪð mɛni dʒɔz. əz ðoʊ taɪm hæd sloʊd, ən ʃi kəd wɑtʃ ði aɪɝn dʒɔz kɹip kloʊsɝ təɡɛðɝ. ðə dʒɹim hæd nɑt feɪɾəd wɪð weɪkɪŋ, ðə weɪ dʒɹimz dɪd. ən ðə deɪnʒɝ fɛl soʊ stʃɹɔŋ ʃi stɪl wɑntəd tə lʊk oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ - oʊnli sʌmhaʊ ʃi nu ðəɾ ɪt wɑz eɪmd ət ɹænd, nɑɾ ət hɝ.

"I - I don't think they're in the Blight, or back in Fal Dara. I had a dream." She said it half defiantly. It sounded silly when she said it, but it had seemed so real. A nightmare for true, but real. First there had been a man with a mask over his face, and fire in place of his eyes. Despite the mask, she had thought he was surprised to see her. His look had frightened her till she thought her bones would break from shivering, but suddenly he vanished, and she saw Rand sleeping on the ground, wrapped in a cloak. A woman had been standing over him, looking down. Her face was in shadow, but her eyes seemed to shine like the moon, and Egwene had known she was evil. Then there was a flash of light, and they were gone. Both of them. And behind it all, almost like another thing altogether, was the feel of danger, as if a trap was just beginning to snap shut on an unsuspecting lamb, a trap with many jaws. As though time had slowed, and she could watch the iron jaws creep closer together. The dream had not faded with waking, the way dreams did. And the danger felt so strong she still wanted to look over her shoulder - only somehow she knew that it was aimed at Rand, not at her.

ʃi wʌndɝɾ ɪf ðə wʊmən hæd bɪn mɔɪɹeɪn, ən əpbɹeɪɾɪd hɝsɛlf fəɹ ðə θɔt. liɑnʒɹɪn fɪt ðət pɑɹt bɛɾɝ. əɹ pɝhæps ɑlɑnə; ʃi hæd bɪn ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn ɹænd, tu.

She wondered if the woman had been Moiraine, and upbraided herself for the thought. Liandrin fit that part better. Or perhaps Alanna; she had been interested in Rand, too.

ʃi kəd nɑt bɹɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə tɛl æneɪjə. fɔɹməli, ʃi sɛd, "æneɪjə sədaɪ, aɪ noʊ ɪt saʊnz fulɪʃ, bʌt hiz ɪn deɪnʒɝ. ɡɹeɪt deɪnʒɝ. aɪ noʊ ɪt. aɪ kəd fil ɪt. aɪ stɪl kæn."

She could not bring herself to tell Anaiya. Formally, she said, "Anaiya Sedai, I know it sounds foolish, but he is in danger. Great danger. I know it. I could feel it. I still can."

æneɪjə wɔɹ ə θɔtfəl lʊk. "wɛl, naʊ," ʃi sɛd sɔfli, "ðæts ə pɑsəbɪləɾi əl weɪdʒɝ noʊ wʌn əz kənsɪɾɝd. jə meɪ bi ə dʒɹimɝ. ɪts ə smɔl tʃæns, tʃaɪld, bʌt. . . . wi hævən hæd wʌn ə ðoʊz ɪn - oʊ - fɔɹ əɹ faɪv hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz. ən dʒɹimɪŋ ɪz kloʊs lɪŋk tə fɔɹtɛlɪŋ. ɪf jə ɹɪli kən dʒɹim, ɪt meɪ bi ðət jə kən fɔɹtɛl, əz wɛl. ðət wəd bi ə fɪŋɡɝ ɪn ðə ɹɛdz' aɪ. ʌv kɔɹs, ɪt kəd bi dʒʌst ən ɔɹɾənɛɹi naɪtmɛɹ, bɹɔɾ ɑn baɪ ə leɪt naɪt, ən koʊl fud, ən əs tʃɹævlɪŋ soʊ hɑɹd sɪns wi lɛft fæl dæɹə. ən jə mɪsɪŋ jəɹ jʌŋ mæn. mʌtʃ mɔɹ laɪkli. jɛs, jɛs, tʃaɪld, aɪ noʊ. jə ɑɹ wɝiɾ əbaʊt hɪm. dɪd jəɹ dʒɹim ɪndəkeɪt wʌt kaɪndə deɪnʒɝ?"

Anaiya wore a thoughtful look. "Well, now," she said softly, "that's a possibility I'll wager no one has considered. You may be a Dreamer. It is a small chance, child, but. . . . We haven't had one of those in - oh - four or five hundred years. And Dreaming is close linked to Foretelling. If you really can Dream, it may be that you can Foretell, as well. That would be a finger in the Reds' eye. Of course, it could be just an ordinary nightmare, brought on by a late night, and cold food, and us traveling so hard since we left Fal Dara. And you missing your young man. Much more likely. Yes, yes, child, I know. You are worried about him. Did your dream indicate what kind of danger?"

ɛɡwin ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "hi dʒʌs vænɪʃt, ən aɪ fɛl deɪnʒɝ. ən ivəl. aɪ fɛlt ɪɾ ivən bɪfɔɹ i vænɪʃt." ʃi ʃɪvɝɾ ən ɹʌbd əɹ hænz təɡɛðɝ. "aɪ kən stɪl fil ɪt."

Egwene shook her head. "He just vanished, and I felt danger. And evil. I felt it even before he vanished." She shivered and rubbed her hands together. "I can still feel it."

"wɛl, wɪl tɔk əbaʊɾ ɪt mɔɹ ɑn ðə ɹɪvɝ kwin. ɪf jə ɑɹ ə dʒɹimɝ, əl si juv ðə tʃɹeɪnɪŋ mɔɪɹeɪn ʃəd bi hɪɹ tə. . . . jə ðɛɹ!" ði ɛɛs sədaɪ bɑɹk sʌɾənli, ən ɛɡwin dʒʌmpt. ə tɔl mæn, hu hæd dʒʌst sæt daʊn ɑn ə kæsk ʌv waɪn, dʒʌmpt, tu. sɛvɹəl ʌðɝz kwɪkən ðɛɹ stɛp. "ðæts fəɹ loʊɾɪŋ əbɔɹd, nɑt ɹɛstɪŋ ɑn! wɪl tɔk ɑn ðə boʊt, tʃaɪld. noʊ, jə ful! jə kæn kæɹi ɪt baɪ jɝsɛlf! dʒju wɑnə hɝt jɝsɛlf?" æneɪjə wɛn stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ ɔf daʊn ðə dɑk, ɡɪvɪŋ ði ənfɔɹtʃənət vɪlɪdʒɝz ə ɹʌfɝ saɪɾ ə hɝ tʌŋ ðən ɛɡwin wʊɾə səspɛktəd ʃi hæd.

"Well, we will talk about it more on the River Queen. If you are a Dreamer, I will see you have the training Moiraine should be here to. . . . You there!" the Aes Sedai barked suddenly, and Egwene jumped. A tall man, who had just sat down on a cask of wine, jumped, too. Several others quickened their step. "That's for loading aboard, not resting on! We will talk on the boat, child. No, you fool! You can't carry it by yourself! Do you want to hurt yourself?" Anaiya went striding off down the dock, giving the unfortunate villagers a rougher side of her tongue than Egwene would have suspected she had.

ɛɡwin pɪɹɾ ɪndə ðə dɑɹk, təwɔɹd ðə saʊθ. hi wɑz aʊt ðɛɹ, sʌmwɛɹ. nɑɾ ɪn fæl dæɹə, nɑɾ ɪn ðə blaɪt. ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ʌv ɪt. hoʊld ɑn, jə wʊl-hɛɾəd ɪɾiət. ɪf jə ɡɛt jɝsɛlf kɪl bɪfɔɹ aɪ kən ɡɛt jə aʊɾ ə ðɪs, əl skɪn jə əlaɪv. ɪt dɪd nɑɾ əkɝ tə hɝ tə æsk haʊ ʃi wɑz gɑnə ɡɛɾ ɪm aʊɾ ʌv ɛniθɪŋ, ɡoʊɪŋ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn əz ʃi wɑz.

Egwene peered into the dark, toward the south. He was out there, somewhere. Not in Fal Dara, not in the Blight. She was sure of it. Hold on, you wool-headed idiot. If you get yourself killed before I can get you out of this, I will skin you alive. It did not occur to her to ask how she was going to get him out of anything, going to Tar Valon as she was.

snʌɡɪŋ əɹ kloʊk ɝaʊn hɝ, ʃi sɛɾ aʊt tə faɪn ə boʊt tə ðə ɹɪvɝ kwin.

Snugging her cloak around her, she set out to find a boat to the River Queen.


tʃæptɝ θɝtin


CHAPTER 13

fɹəm stoʊn tə stoʊn


From Stone to Stone

ðə laɪɾ ə ðə ɹaɪzɪŋ sʌn woʊk ɹænd, ən i wʌndɝɾ ɪf i wɝ dʒɹimɪŋ. hi sæɾ ʌp sloʊli, stɛɹɪŋ. ɛvɹiθɪŋ hæd tʃeɪnʒd, əɹ ɔlmoʊst ɛvɹiθɪŋ. ðə sʌn ən ðə skaɪ wɝ əz i ɪkspɛktəd tə si, ɪf pæləɾ ən ɔl bʌt klaʊdləs. lɔɪəl ən hʊɹɪn stɪl leɪ ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ə hɪm, ɹæpt ɪn ðɛɹ kloʊks əslip, ən ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz stɪl stʊd hɑbəld ə peɪs əweɪ, bʌɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls wɑz ɡɔn. soʊlʒɝz, hɔɹsəz, hɪz fɹɛnz, ɛvɹiwʌn ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɡɔn.

The light of the rising sun woke Rand, and he wondered if he were dreaming. He sat up slowly, staring. Everything had changed, or almost everything. The sun and the sky were as he expected to see, if pallid and all but cloudless. Loial and Hurin still lay on either side of him, wrapped in their cloaks asleep, and their horses still stood hobbled a pace away, but everyone else was gone. Soldiers, horses, his friends, everyone and everything gone.

ðə hɑloʊ ɪtsɛlf hæd tʃeɪnʒd, tu, ən ðeɪ wɝ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ɪt naʊ, noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɑn ði ɛdʒ. ət ɹændz hɛd ɹoʊz ə ɡɹeɪ stoʊn sɪləndɝ, ɛvɹi bɪɾ ə θɹi spænz haɪ ən ə fʊl peɪs θɪk, kʌvɝd wɪð hʌnʒɹədz, pɝhæps θaʊzənz, ʌv dipli ɪnsaɪz daɪəɡɹæmz ən mɑɹkɪŋz ɪn səm læŋɡwədʒ i dɪd nɑt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz. waɪt stoʊn peɪv ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə hɑloʊ, əz lɛvəl əz ə flɔɹ, pɑlɪʃt soʊ smuð ɪɾ ɔlmoʊst ɡlɪsənd. bɹɔd, haɪ stɛps ɹoʊz tə ðə ɹɪm ɪn kənsɛntʃɹɪk ɹɪŋz ə dɪfɹən kʌlɝd stoʊn. ən əbaʊt ðə ɹɪm, ðə tʃɹiz stʊd blækən ən twɪstəɾ əz ɪf ə faɪɹstɔɹm hæd ɹɔɹd θɹu ðɛm. ɛvɹiθɪŋ sim pəlɝ ðən ɪt ʃəd bi, dʒʌs laɪk ðə sʌn, mɔɹ səbdud, əz ɪf sin θɹu mɪst. oʊnli ðəɹ wɑz noʊ mɪst. dʒʌs ðə θɹi ʌv əm ən ðə hɔɹsəz əpɪɹd tʃɹuli sɑləd. bʌt wən i tʌtʃt ðə stoʊn ʌndɝ hɪm, ɪt fɛl sɑləɾ ɪnʌf.

The hollow itself had changed, too, and they were in the middle of it now, no longer on the edge. At Rand's head rose a gray stone cylinder, every bit of three spans high and a full pace thick, covered with hundreds, perhaps thousands, of deeply incised diagrams and markings in some language he did not recognize. White stone paved the bottom of the hollow, as level as a floor, polished so smooth it almost glistened. Broad, high steps rose to the rim in concentric rings of different colored stone. And about the rim, the trees stood blackened and twisted as if a firestorm had roared through them. Everything seemed paler than it should be, just like the sun, more subdued, as if seen through mist. Only there was no mist. Just the three of them and the horses appeared truly solid. But when he touched the stone under him, it felt solid enough.

hi ɹitʃt aʊɾ ən ʃʊk lɔɪəl ən hʊɹɪn. "weɪk ʌp! weɪk ʌp ən tɛl mi aɪm dʒɹimɪŋ. pliz weɪk ʌp!"

He reached out and shook Loial and Hurin. "Wake up! Wake up and tell me I'm dreaming. Please wake up!"

"ɪz ɪt mɔɹnɪŋ ɔlɹɛɾi?" lɔɪəl bɪɡæn, sɪɾɪŋ ʌp, ðən ɪz maʊθ fɛl oʊpən, ən ɪz bɪɡ, ɹaʊn aɪz ɡɹu waɪɾɝ ən waɪɾɝ.

"Is it morning already?" Loial began, sitting up, then his mouth fell open, and his big, round eyes grew wider and wider.

hʊɹɪn woʊk wɪð ə stɑɹt, ðən lɛp tə hɪz fit, dʒʌmpɪŋ laɪk ə fli ɑn ə hɑt ɹɑk tə lʊk ðɪs weɪ, ðən ðæt. "wɛɹ ɑɹ wi? wʌts hæpənd? wɛɹ ɪz ɛvɹibɑɾi? wɛɹ ɑɹ wi, lɔɹd ɹænd?" hi sæŋk tə hɪz niz, ɹɪŋɪŋ ɪz hænz, bʌɾ ɪz aɪz stɪl dɑɹɾɪd. "wʌts hæpənd?"

Hurin woke with a start, then leaped to his feet, jumping like a flea on a hot rock to look this way, then that. "Where are we? What's happened? Where is everybody? Where are we, Lord Rand?" He sank to his knees, wringing his hands, but his eyes still darted. "What's happened?"

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ," ɹænd sɛd sloʊli. "aɪ wɑz hoʊpɪŋ ɪt wɑz ə dʒɹim, bʌt. . . . meɪbi ɪts ə dʒɹim." hi hæd hæɾ ɪkspɪɹiəns ə dʒɹimz ðət wɝ nɑt dʒɹimz, ɪkspɪɹiəns i wɑntəd niðɝ tə ɹɪpit nɔɹ tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ. hi stʊɾ ʌp kɛɹfəli. ɛvɹiθɪŋ steɪɾ əz ɪt wɑz.

"I don't know," Rand said slowly. "I was hoping it was a dream, but. . . . Maybe it is a dream." He had had experience of dreams that were not dreams, experience he wanted neither to repeat nor to remember. He stood up carefully. Everything stayed as it was.

"aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk soʊ," lɔɪəl sɛd. hi wɑz stʌɾiɪŋ ðə kɑləm, ən i dɪd nɑɾ əpɪɹ hæpi. hɪz lɔŋ aɪbɹaʊz sæɡd əkɹɔs ɪz tʃiks, ən ɪz tʌftəɾ ɪɹz sim tə hæv wɪltɪd. "aɪ θɪŋk ðɪs ɪz ðə seɪm stoʊn wi wɛn tə slip bɪsaɪd læs naɪt. aɪ θɪŋk aɪ noʊ wʌɾ ɪɾ ɪz, naʊ." fəɹ wʌns, hi saʊndəd mɪzɝəbəl əbaʊt noʊɪŋ.

"I do not think so," Loial said. He was studying the column, and he did not appear happy. His long eyebrows sagged across his cheeks, and his tufted ears seemed to have wilted. "I think this is the same stone we went to sleep beside last night. I think I know what it is, now." For once, he sounded miserable about knowing.

"ðæts. . . ." noʊ. ðət biɪŋ ðə seɪm stoʊn wɑz noʊ mɔɹ kɹeɪzi ðən wʌɾ i kəd si ɝaʊn hɪm, mæt ən pɛɹɪn ən ðə ʃaɪnɝənz ɡɔn, ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ tʃeɪnʒd. aɪ θɔɾ aɪɾ ɪskeɪpt, bʌɾ ɪts stɑɹɾəd əɡɛn, ən ðɛɹz noʊ sətʃ θɪŋ əz kɹeɪzi ɛnimɔɹ. ənlɛs aɪ æm. hi lʊkt ət lɔɪəl ən hʊɹɪn. ðeɪ wɝ nɑɾ æktɪŋ əz ɪf i wɝ mæd; ðeɪ sɔ ɪt, tu. sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ðə stɛps kɑɾ ɪz aɪ, ðə dɪfɹən kʌlɝz, sɛvən ɹaɪzɪŋ fɹəm blu tə ɹɛd. "wʌn fəɹ itʃ ədʒɑ," hi sɛd.

"That's. . . ." No. That being the same stone was no more crazy than what he could see around him, Mat and Perrin and the Shienarans gone, and everything changed. I thought I'd escaped, but it's started again, and there's no such thing as crazy anymore. Unless I am. He looked at Loial and Hurin. They were not acting as if he were mad; they saw it, too. Something about the steps caught his eye, the different colors, seven rising from blue to red. "One for each Ajah," he said.

"noʊ, lɔɹd ɹænd," hʊɹɪn moʊnd. "noʊ. ɛɛs sədaɪ wəd nɑt də ðɪs tə ʌs. ðeɪ wʊdnt! aɪ wɔk ɪn ðə laɪt."

"No, Lord Rand," Hurin moaned. "No. Aes Sedai would not do this to us. They wouldn't! I walk in the Light."

"wi ɔl du, hʊɹɪn," ɹænd sɛd. "ði ɛɛs sədaɪ woʊn hɝt ju." ənlɛs jə ɡɛɾ ɪn ðə weɪ. kəd ðɪs bi mɔɪɹeɪnz duɪŋ sʌmhaʊ? "lɔɪəl, jə sɛd jə noʊ wʌt ðə stoʊn ɪz. wʌɾ ɪz ɪt?"

"We all do, Hurin," Rand said. "The Aes Sedai won't hurt you." Unless you get in the way. Could this be Moiraine's doing somehow? "Loial, you said you know what the stone is. What is it?"

"aɪ sɛɾ aɪ θɪŋk aɪ noʊ, ɹænd. ðəɹ wɑz ə pis ʌv ən oʊl bʊk, dʒʌst ə fju peɪdʒəz, bʌt wʌn ə ðɛm hæɾ ə dʒɹɔɪŋ ə ðɪs stoʊn, ðɪs stoʊn" - ðəɹ wɑz ə dɪstɪŋk dɪfɝəns ɪn ðə weɪ hi sɛɾ ɪt ðət mɑɹkt ɪmpɔɹɾəns - "ɔɹ wʌn vɛɹi laɪk ɪt. ən ʌndɝniθ, ɪt sɛd, 'fɹʌm stoʊn tə stoʊn ɹʌn ðə laɪnz ʌv "ɪf," bɪtwin ðə wɝlz ðət maɪt bi.' "

"I said I think I know, Rand. There was a piece of an old book, just a few pages, but one of them had a drawing of this stone, this Stone" - there was a distinct difference in the way he said it that marked importance - "or one very like it. And underneath, it said, 'From Stone to Stone run the lines of "if," between the worlds that might be.' "

"wʌt dʌz ðət min, lɔɪəl? ɪt dʌzn meɪk ɛni sɛns."

"What does that mean, Loial? It doesn't make any sense."

ði oʊɡiɝ ʃʊk ɪz mæsɪv hɛd sædli. "ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə fju peɪdʒəz. pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt sɛɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz, səm ə ðoʊz u kəd tʃɹævəl, ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl ə ðɛm, kəd juz ðiz stoʊnz. ɪt dɪd nɑt seɪ haʊ, bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk, fɹəm wʌɾ aɪ kəd pʌzəl aʊt, ðət pɝhæps ðoʊz ɛɛs sədaɪ juz ðə stoʊnz sʌmhaʊ tə dʒɝni tə ðoʊz wɝlz." hi ɡlænst ʌp ət ðə sɪɹd tʃɹiz ən pʊld ɪz aɪz daʊn əɡɛn kwɪkli, əz i dɪd nɑt wɑnə θɪŋk əbaʊt wʌt leɪ bɪɑn ðə ɹɪm. "jɛɾ ivən ɪf ɛɛs sədaɪ kən juz ðɛm, əɹ kʊd, wi hæd noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪð əs tə tʃænəl ðə paʊɝ, soʊ aɪ doʊn si haʊ ɪt kən bi."

The Ogier shook his massive head sadly. "It was only a few pages. Part of it said Aes Sedai in the Age of Legends, some of those who could Travel, the most powerful of them, could use these Stones. It did not say how, but I think, from what I could puzzle out, that perhaps those Aes Sedai used the Stones somehow to journey to those worlds." He glanced up at the seared trees and pulled his eyes down again quickly, as he did not want to think about what lay beyond the rim. "Yet even if Aes Sedai can use them, or could, we had no Aes Sedai with us to channel the Power, so I don't see how it can be."

ɹændz skɪn pɹɪkəld. ɛɛs sədaɪ juz ðɛm. ɪn ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz, wən ðəɹ wɝ meɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ. hi hæɾ ə veɪɡ mɛmɹi ʌv ðə vɔɪd kloʊzɪŋ ɹaʊn ɪm əz i fɛl əslip, fɪld wɪð ðəɾ ənizi ɡloʊ. ən i ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðə ɹum ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ, ən ðə laɪɾ i hæd ɹitʃt fəɹ tə ɪskeɪp. ɪf ðət wɑz ðə meɪl hæf ə tʃɹu sɔɹs. . . . noʊ, ɪt kæn bi. bʌt wʌɾ ɪf ɪɾ ɪz? laɪt, aɪ wɑz wʌndɝɪŋ wɛðɝ tə ɹʌn əɹ nɑt, ən ɔl ðə taɪm ɪts ɹaɪɾ ɪnsaɪd maɪ hɛd. meɪbi aɪ bɹɔɾ əs hɪɹ. hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə θɪŋk əbaʊɾ ɪt. "wɝlz ðət maɪt bi? aɪ doʊn ʌndɝstænd, lɔɪəl."

Rand's skin prickled. Aes Sedai used them. In the Age of Legends, when there were male Aes Sedai. He had a vague memory of the void closing round him as he fell asleep, filled with that uneasy glow. And he remembered the room in the village, and the light he had reached for to escape. If that was the male half of True Source. . . . No, it can't be. But what if it is? Light, I was wondering whether to run or not, and all the time it's right inside my head. Maybe I brought us here. He did not want to think about it. "Worlds that might be? I don't understand, Loial."

ði oʊɡiɝ ʃɹʌɡd mæsɪvli, ən ənizəli. "niðɝ də aɪ, ɹænd. moʊst ʌv ɪt saʊndəd laɪk ðɪs. 'ɪf ə wʊmən ɡoʊ lɛft, əɹ ɹaɪt, dʌz taɪmz floʊ dɪvaɪd? dʌz ðə wil ðən wiv tu pæɾɝnz? ə θaʊzənd, fəɹ itʃ ə hɝ tɝnɪŋz? əz mɛni əz ðə stɑɹz? ɪz wʌn ɹil, ði ʌðɝz mɪɹli ʃædoʊz ən ɹɪflɛkʃənz?' jə si, ɪt wɑz nɑt vɛɹi klɪɹ. meɪnli kwɛstʃənz, moʊst ʌv wɪtʃ sim tə kɑntʃɹədɪkt itʃ ʌðɝ. ən ðəɹ dʒʌst wɑzn mʌtʃ ʌv ɪt." hi wɛn bæk tə stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə kɑləm, bʌɾ i lʊkt əz ɪf i wɪʃt ɪt wəd ɡoʊ əweɪ. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ səpoʊz tə bi ə ɡʊd mɛni ʌv ðiz stoʊnz, skæɾɝd ɔl oʊvɝ ðə wɝld, əɹ ðəɹ wɝ, wʌns, bʌɾ aɪ nɛvɝ hɝɾ ʌv ɛniwʌn faɪndɪŋ wʌn. aɪ nɛvɝ hɝɾ ʌv ɛniwʌn faɪndɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ laɪk ðɪs əɾ ɔl."

The Ogier shrugged massively, and uneasily. "Neither do I, Rand. Most of it sounded like this. 'If a woman go left, or right, does Time's flow divide? Does the Wheel then weave two Patterns? A thousand, for each of her turnings? As many as the stars? Is one real, the others merely shadows and reflections?' You see, it was not very clear. Mainly questions, most of which seemed to contradict each other. And there just wasn't much of it." He went back to staring at the column, but he looked as if he wished it would go away. "There are supposed to be a good many of these Stones, scattered all over the world, or there were, once, but I never heard of anyone finding one. I never heard of anyone finding anything like this at all."

"maɪ lɔɹd ɹænd?" naʊ ɑn ɪz fit, hʊɹɪn sim kɑmɝ, bʌɾ i klʌtʃt ɪz koʊɾ ət ðə weɪst wɪð boʊθ hænz, hɪz feɪs ɝdʒənt. "maɪ lɔɹd ɹænd, jəl ɡɛɾ əs bæk, woʊn ju? bæk wɛɹ wi bɪlɔŋ? aɪv ə waɪf, maɪ lɔɹd, ən tʃɪlʒɹən. mɛliəd teɪk ɪt bæɾ ɪnʌf, mi daɪɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪf ʃi dʌzn ivən əv maɪ bɑɾi tə ɡɪv tə ðə mʌðɝz ɛmbɹeɪs, ʃɪl ɡɹiv tə ði ɛn ə hɝ deɪz. jə ʌndɝstænd, maɪ lɔɹd. aɪ kæn liv əɹ nɑt noʊɪŋ. jəl ɡɛɾ əs bæk. ən ɪf aɪ daɪ, ɪf jə kæn teɪk əɹ maɪ bɑɾi, jəl lɛɾ əɹ noʊ, soʊ ʃiz ðæt, ət list." hi wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ kwɛstʃənɪŋ ət ði ɛnd. ə noʊɾ ə kɑnfəɾəns hæd kɹɛpt ɪndə hɪz vɔɪs.

"My Lord Rand?" Now on his feet, Hurin seemed calmer, but he clutched his coat at the waist with both hands, his face urgent. "My Lord Rand, you'll get us back, won't you? Back where we belong? I've a wife, my Lord, and children. Melia'd take it bad enough, me dying, but if she doesn't even have my body to give to the mother's embrace, she'll grieve to the end of her days. You understand, my Lord. I can't leave her not knowing. You'll get us back. And if I die, if you can't take her my body, you'll let her know, so she has that, at least." He was no longer questioning at the end. A note of confidence had crept into his voice.

ɹænd oʊpən ɪz maʊθ tə seɪ əɡɛn i wɑz nɑɾ ə lɔɹd, ðən ʃʌɾ ɪt wɪθaʊt spikɪŋ. ðət wɑz hɑɹdli ɪmpɔɹɾənt ɪnʌf tə mɛnʃən, naʊ. jə ɡɑɾ ɪm ɪndə ðɪs. hi wɑntəd tə dɪnaɪ ɪt, bʌɾ i nu wʌɾ i wɑz, nu hi kəd tʃænəl, ivən ɪf ɪɾ ɔlweɪz sim tə hæpən ɔl baɪ ɪtsɛlf. lɔɪəl sɛɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ juz ðə stoʊnz, ən ðət mɛn ðə wʌn paʊɝ. wʌt lɔɪəl sɛɾ i nu, jə kəd bi ʃʊɹ ʌv - ði oʊɡiɝ nɛvɝ kleɪm tə noʊ ɪf i dɪd nɑt - ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ wʌn ɛls nɪɹbaɪ hu kəd wil ðə paʊɝ. jə ɡɑɾ ɪm ɪndə ɪt, juv tə ɡɛɾ ɪm aʊt. juv tə tʃɹaɪ.

Rand opened his mouth to say again he was not a lord, then shut it without speaking. That was hardly important enough to mention, now. You got him into this. He wanted to deny it, but he knew what he was, knew he could channel, even if it always seemed to happen all by itself. Loial said Aes Sedai used the Stones, and that meant the One Power. What Loial said he knew, you could be sure of - the Ogier never claimed to know if he did not - and there was no one else nearby who could wield the Power. You got him into it, you have to get him out. You have to try.

"aɪ wɪl də maɪ bɛst, hʊɹɪn." ən kəz hʊɹɪn wɑz ʃaɪnɝən, hi æɾəd, "baɪ maɪ haʊs ən ɑnɝ. ə ʃɛpɝdz haʊs ən ə ʃɛpɝdz ɑnɝ, bʌɾ əl meɪk əm də əz wɛl əz ə lɔɹdz."

"I will do my best, Hurin." And because Hurin was Shienaran, he added, "By my House and honor. A shepherd's House and a shepherd's honor, but I'll make them do as well as a lord's."

hʊɹɪn lust ɪz hoʊld ɑn ɪz koʊt. ðə kɑnfəɾəns ɹitʃt ɪz aɪz, tu. hi baʊd dipli. "ɑnɝ tə sɝv, maɪ lɔɹd."

Hurin loosed his hold on his coat. The confidence reached his eyes, too. He bowed deeply. "Honor to serve, my Lord."

ɡɪlt ɹɪpəl θɹu ɹænd. hi θɪŋks jəl si hɪm hoʊm, naʊ, kəz ʃaɪnɝən lɔɹdz ɔlweɪz kip ðɛɹ wɝd. wʌɾ ɑɹ jə ɡoʊɪŋ tə du, lɔɹd ɹænd? "nʌn ə ðæt, hʊɹɪn. ðɛɹəl bi noʊ boʊɪŋ. aɪm nɑt - " sʌɾənli hi nu hi kəd nɑt tɛl ðə mæn əɡɛn ðəɾ i wɑz nɑɾ ə lɔɹd. ɔl ðət wɑz hoʊldɪŋ ðə snɪfɝ təɡɛðɝ wɑz ɪz bɪlif ɪn ə lɔɹd, ən i kəd nɑt teɪk ðəɾ əweɪ, nɑt naʊ. nɑt hɪɹ. "noʊ boʊɪŋ," hi fɪnɪʃt ɔkwɝdli.

Guilt rippled through Rand. He thinks you'll see him home, now, because Shienaran lords always keep their word. What are you going to do, Lord Rand? "None of that, Hurin. There'll be no bowing. I'm not - " Suddenly he knew he could not tell the man again that he was not a lord. All that was holding the sniffer together was his belief in a lord, and he could not take that away, not now. Not here. "No bowing," he finished awkwardly.

"æz jə seɪ, lɔɹd ɹænd." hʊɹɪnz ɡɹɪn wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz waɪɾ əz wən ɹænd fɝs mɛt hɪm.

"As you say, Lord Rand." Hurin's grin was almost as wide as when Rand first met him.

ɹænd klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊt. "jɛs. wɛl, ðæts wʌɾ aɪ seɪ."

Rand cleared his throat. "Yes. Well, that's what I say."

ðeɪ wɝ boʊθ wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm, lɔɪəl kjʊɹiəs, hʊɹɪn kɑnfəɾənt, boʊθ weɪɾɪŋ tə si wʌɾ i wəd du. aɪ bɹɔɾ əm hɪɹ. aɪ mʌs hæv. soʊ aɪ hæv tə ɡɛɾ əm bæk. ən ðət minz. . . .

They were both watching him, Loial curious, Hurin confident, both waiting to see what he would do. I brought them here. I must have. So I have to get them back. And that means. . . .

dʒɹɔɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ, hi wɔkt əkɹɔs ðə waɪt peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz tə ðə sɪmbəl-kʌvɝd sɪləndɝ. smɔl laɪnz ə səm læŋɡwədʒ i dɪd nɑt noʊ sɝaʊndəɾ itʃ sɪmbəl, ɑd lɛɾɝz ðət floʊɾ ɪn kɝvz ən spaɪɹəlz, sʌɾənli tɝn tə dʒæɡd hʊks ən æŋɡəlz, ðən floʊɾ ɑn. ət list ɪt wɑz nɑt tʃɹɑlɑk skɹɪpt. ɹɪlʌktənli, hi pʊɾ ɪz hænz ɑn ðə kɑləm. ɪt lʊk laɪk ɛni dʒɹaɪ, pɑlɪʃt stoʊn, bʌɾ ɪt fɛl kjʊɹiəsli slɪk, laɪk ɔɪl mɛɾəl.

Drawing a deep breath, he walked across the white paving stones to the symbol-covered cylinder. Small lines of some language he did not know surrounded each symbol, odd letters that flowed in curves and spirals, suddenly turned to jagged hooks and angles, then flowed on. At least it was not Trolloc script. Reluctantly, he put his hands on the column. It looked like any dry, polished stone, but it felt curiously slick, like oiled metal.

hi kloʊzd ɪz aɪz ən fɔɹm ðə fleɪm. ðə vɔɪd keɪm sloʊli, hɛzɪɾəntli. hi nu hɪz oʊn fɪɹ wɑz hoʊldɪŋ ɪt bæk, fɪɹ ʌv wʌɾ i wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ. əz fæst əz i fɛd fɪɹ ɪndə ðə fleɪm, mɔɹ keɪm. aɪ kæn də ɪt. tʃænəl ðə paʊɝ. aɪ doʊnt wɑn tə. laɪt, ðəɹ əz tə bi ənʌðɝ weɪ. ɡɹɪmli hi fɔɹs ðə θɔts tə stɪlnəs. hi kəd fil swɛt biɾɪŋ ɑn ɪz feɪs. dətɝmənədli hi kɛpt ɑn, pʊʃɪŋ ɪz fɪɹz ɪndə ðə kənsumɪŋ fleɪm, meɪkɪŋ ɪt ɡɹoʊ, ən ɡɹoʊ. ən ðə vɔɪd wɑz ðɛɹ.

He closed his eyes and formed the flame. The void came slowly, hesitantly. He knew his own fear was holding it back, fear of what he was trying. As fast as he fed fear into the flame, more came. I can't do it. Channel the Power. I don't want to. Light, there has to be another way. Grimly he forced the thoughts to stillness. He could feel sweat beading on his face. Determinedly he kept on, pushing his fears into the consuming flame, making it grow, and grow. And the void was there.

ðə kɔɹ ə hɪm floʊɾəd ɪn ɛmptinəs. hi kəd si ðə laɪt - seɪɾɪn - ivən wɪð ɪz aɪz kloʊzd, fil ðə wɔɹmθ ʌv ɪt, sɝaʊndɪŋ hɪm, sɝaʊndɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ, sʌfjuzɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ. ɪt weɪvɝd laɪk ə kændəl fleɪm sin θɹu ɔɪl peɪpɝ. ɹænsɪɾ ɔɪl. stɪŋkɪŋ ɔɪl.

The core of him floated in emptiness. He could see the light - saidin - even with his eyes closed, feel the warmth of it, surrounding him, surrounding everything, suffusing everything. It wavered like a candle flame seen through oiled paper. Rancid oil. Stinking oil.

hi ɹitʃt fəɹ ɪt - hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ haʊ hi ɹitʃt, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz sʌmθɪŋ, ə muvmənt, ə stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə laɪt, təwɔɹd seɪɾɪn - ən kɑt nʌθɪŋ, əz ɪf ɹʌnɪŋ ɪz hænz θɹu wɔɾɝ. ɪt fɛlt laɪk ə slaɪmi pɑnd, skʌm floʊɾɪŋ ətɑp klin wɔɾɝ bɪloʊ, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt skup ʌp ɛni ʌv ðə wɔɾɝ. taɪm ən əɡɛn ɪt tʃɹɪkəl θɹu hɪz fɪŋɡɝz, nɑɾ ivən dʒɹɑpləts ə ðə wɔɾɝ ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ, oʊnli ðə slɪk skʌm, meɪkɪŋ ɪz skɪn kɹɔl.

He reached for it - he was not sure how he reached, but it was something, a movement, a stretching toward the light, toward saidin - and caught nothing, as if running his hands through water. It felt like a slimy pond, scum floating atop clean water below, but he could not scoop up any of the water. Time and again it trickled through his fingers, not even droplets of the water remaining, only the slick scum, making his skin crawl.

dɛspɝətli, hi tʃɹaɪd tə fɔɹm ən ɪmədʒ ə ðə hɑloʊ əz ɪt hæd bɪn, wɪð ɪŋtʃɹ ən ðə lænsɪz slipɪŋ baɪ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz, wɪð mæt ən pɛɹɪn, ən ðə stoʊn laɪɪŋ bɛɹiɾ ɪksɛp fəɹ wʌn ɛnd. aʊtsaɪd ðə vɔɪɾ i fɔɹmd ɪt, klɪŋɪŋ tə ðə ʃɛl ʌv ɛmptinəs ðəɾ ɛnkloʊz hɪm. hi tʃɹaɪd tə lɪŋk ði ɪmədʒ wɪð ðə laɪt, tʃɹaɪd tə fɔɹs əm təɡɛðɝ. ðə hɑloʊ əz ɪt hæd bɪn, ən i ən lɔɪəl ən hʊɹɪn ðəɹ təɡɛðɝ. hɪz hɛd hɝt. təɡɛðɝ, wɪð mæt ən pɛɹɪn ən ðə ʃaɪnɝənz. bɝnɪŋ, ɪn ɪz hɛd. təɡɛðɝ!

Desperately, he tried to form an image of the hollow as it had been, with Ingtar and the lances sleeping by their horses, with Mat and Perrin, and the Stone lying buried except for one end. Outside the void he formed it, clinging to the shell of emptiness that enclosed him. He tried to link the image with the light, tried to force them together. The hollow as it had been, and he and Loial and Hurin there together. His head hurt. Together, with Mat and Perrin and the Shienarans. Burning, in his head. Together!

ðə vɔɪd ʃæɾɝd ɪndə ə θaʊzən ɹeɪzɝ ʃɑɹdz, slaɪsɪŋ ɪz maɪnd.

The void shattered into a thousand razor shards, slicing his mind.

ʃʌɾɝɪŋ, hi stæɡɝd bæk, waɪd-aɪd. hɪz hænz hɝt fɹəm pɹɛsɪŋ ðə stoʊn, ən ɪz ɑɹmz ən ʃoʊldɝz kwɪvɝd wɪð eɪkɪŋ; hɪz stʌmək lɝtʃt fɹəm ðə fil ə fɪlθ kʌvɝɪŋ hɪm, ən ɪz hɛd. . . . hi tʃɹaɪd tə stɛɾi hɪz bɹiðɪŋ. ðət hæd nɛvɝ hæpən bɪfɔɹ. wən ðə vɔɪd wɛnt, ɪt wɛn laɪk ə pɹɪk bʌbəl, dʒʌst ɡɔn, ɪn ə twɪŋkəlɪŋ. nɛvɝ bɹoʊkən laɪk ɡlæs. hɪz hɛd fɛl nʌm, əz ɪf ðə θaʊzən slæʃɪz hæd hæpən soʊ kwɪkli ðə peɪn hæd nɑt jɛt kʌm. bʌɾ ɛvɹi kʌt hæd fɛlt əz ɹil əz ɪf dʌn wɪð ə naɪf. hi tʌtʃt ɪz tɛmpəl, ən wɑz sɝpɹaɪz nɑt tə si blʌɾ ɑn ɪz fɪŋɡɝz.

Shuddering, he staggered back, wide-eyed. His hands hurt from pressing the Stone, and his arms and shoulders quivered with aching; his stomach lurched from the feel of filth covering him, and his head. . . . He tried to steady his breathing. That had never happened before. When the void went, it went like a pricked bubble, just gone, in a twinkling. Never broken like glass. His head felt numb, as if the thousand slashes had happened so quickly the pain had not yet come. But every cut had felt as real as if done with a knife. He touched his temple, and was surprised not to see blood on his fingers.

hʊɹɪn stɪl stʊd ðəɹ wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm, stɪl kɑnfəɾənt. ɪf ɛniθɪŋ, ðə snɪfɝ simd mɔɹ ʃʊɹ baɪ ðə mɪnət. lɔɹd ɹænd wɑz duɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ. ðət wɑz wʌt lɔɹdz wɝ fɔɹ. ðeɪ pɹətɛktəd ðə læn ən ðə pipəl wɪð ðɛɹ bɑɾiz ən ðɛɹ laɪvz, ən wən sʌmθɪŋ wɑz ɹɔŋ, ðeɪ sɛɾ ɪɾ æɹaɪɾ ən sɔ fɛɹnəs ən dʒʌstəs dʌn. əz lɔŋ əz ɹænd wɑz duɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ, ɛniθɪŋ, hʊɹɪn wəɾ əv kɑnfəɾəns ðəɾ ɪt wəɾ ɔl kʌm ɹaɪɾ ɪn ði ɛnd. ðət wɑz wʌt lɔɹdz dɪd.

Hurin still stood there watching him, still confident. If anything, the sniffer seemed more sure by the minute. Lord Rand was doing something. That was what lords were for. They protected the land and the people with their bodies and their lives, and when something was wrong, they set it aright and saw fairness and justice done. As long as Rand was doing something, anything, Hurin would have confidence that it would all come right in the end. That was what lords did.

lɔɪəl hæɾ ə dɪfɹən lʊk, ə slaɪtli pʌzəl fɹaʊn, bʌɾ ɪz aɪz wɝ ɑn ɹænd, tu. ɹænd wʌndɝd wʌɾ i wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ.

Loial had a different look, a slightly puzzled frown, but his eyes were on Rand, too. Rand wondered what he was thinking.

"ɪt wɑz wɝθ ə tʃɹaɪ," hi toʊl ðɛm. ðə ɹænsɪɾ ɔɪl fil, ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz hɛd - laɪt, ɪts ɪnsaɪd mi! aɪ doʊnt wɑn ɪɾ ɪnsaɪd mi! - wɑz feɪɾɪŋ sloʊli, bʌɾ i stɪl θɔɾ i maɪt vɑmət. "aɪ wɪl tʃɹaɪ əɡɛn, ɪn ə fju mɪnəts."

"It was worth a try," he told them. The rancid oil feel, inside his head - Light, it's inside me! I don't want it inside me! - was fading slowly, but he still thought he might vomit. "I will try again, in a few minutes."

hi hoʊpt i saʊndəd kɑnfəɾənt. hi hæd noʊ aɪdiə haʊ ðə stoʊnz wɝkt, ɪf wʌɾ i wɑz duɪŋ hæɾ ɛni tʃæns ə səksɛs. meɪbi ðəɹ ɑɹ ɹulz fəɹ wɝkɪŋ ðɛm. meɪbi juv tə də sʌmθɪŋ spɛʃəl. laɪt, meɪbi jə kæn juz ðə seɪm stoʊn twaɪs, ɔɹ. . . . hi kʌɾ ɔf ðət laɪn ə θɔt. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɡʊɾ ɪn θɪŋkɪŋ laɪk ðæt. hi hæd tə də ɪt. lʊkɪŋ ət lɔɪəl ən hʊɹɪn, hi θɔɾ i nu wʌt læn hæd mɛn əbaʊt duɾi pɹɛsɪŋ daʊn laɪk ə maʊntən.

He hoped he sounded confident. He had no idea how the Stones worked, if what he was doing had any chance of success. Maybe there are rules for working them. Maybe you have to do something special. Light, maybe you can't use the same Stone twice, or. . . . He cut off that line of thought. There was no good in thinking like that. He had to do it. Looking at Loial and Hurin, he thought he knew what Lan had meant about duty pressing down like a mountain.

"maɪ lɔɹd, aɪ θɪŋk. . . ." hʊɹɪn lɛɾ ɪz wɝdz tʃɹeɪl ɔf, lʊkɪŋ əbæʃt fəɹ ə moʊmənt. "maɪ lɔɹd, meɪbi, ɪf wi faɪn ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz, wi kən meɪk wʌn ə ðɛm tɛl əs haʊ tə ɡɛt bæk."

"My Lord, I think. . . ." Hurin let his words trail off, looking abashed for a moment. "My Lord, maybe, if we find the Darkfriends, we can make one of them tell us how to get back."

"aɪ wəɾ æsk ə dɑɹkfɹɛn əɹ ðə dɑɹk wʌn hɪmsɛlf ɪf aɪ θɔɾ aɪd ɡɛɾ ə tʃɹu ænsɝ bæk," ɹænd sɛd. "bʌt wəɹ ɔl ðəɹ ɪz. dʒʌst əs θɹi." dʒʌs mi. ɪm ðə wʌn u hæz tə də ɪt.

"I would ask a Darkfriend or the Dark One himself if I thought I'd get a true answer back," Rand said. "But we are all there is. Just us three." Just me. I'm the one who has to do it.

"wi kəd fɑloʊ ðɛɹ tʃɹeɪl, maɪ lɔɹd. ɪf wi kætʃ ðɛm. . . ."

"We could follow their trail, my Lord. If we catch them. . . ."

ɹænd stɛɹɾ ət ðə snɪfɝ. "ju kən stɪl smɛl ðɛm?"

Rand stared at the sniffer. "You can still smell them?"

"aɪ kæn, maɪ lɔɹd." hʊɹɪn fɹaʊnd. "ɪts feɪnt, peɪl-laɪk, laɪk ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls hɪɹ, bʌɾ aɪ kən smɛl ðə tʃɹeɪl. ɹaɪɾ ʌp ðɛɹ." hi pɔɪntəd tə ðə ɹɪm ə ðə hɑloʊ. "aɪ doʊn ʌndɝstæn ɪt, maɪ lɔɹd, bʌt - læs naɪt, aɪ cʊɾə swɔɹn ðə tʃɹeɪl wɛn ɹaɪɾ ɑn baɪ ðə hɑloʊ bæk - bæk wɛɹ wi wɝ. wɛl, ɪts ɪn ðə seɪm pleɪs naʊ, oʊnli hɪɹ, ən feɪntɝ, laɪk aɪ sɛd. nɑɾ oʊld, nɑt feɪn laɪk ðæt, bʌt. . . . aɪ doʊnt noʊ, lɔɹd ɹænd, ɪksɛp ðəɾ ɪts ðɛɹ."

"I can, my Lord." Hurin frowned. "It's faint, pale-like, like everything else here, but I can smell the trail. Right up there." He pointed to the rim of the hollow. "I don't understand it, my Lord, but - Last night, I could have sworn the trail went right on by the hollow back - back where we were. Well, it's in the same place now, only here, and fainter, like I said. Not old, not faint like that, but. . . . I don't know, Lord Rand, except that it's there."

ɹænd kənsɪɾɝd. ɪf feɪn ən ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz wɝ hɪɹ - wɛɹɛvɝ hɪɹ wɑz - ðeɪ maɪt noʊ haʊ tə ɡɛt bæk. ðeɪ hæd tə, ɪf ðeɪ hæd ɹitʃt hɪɹ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs. ən ðeɪ hæd ðə hɔɹn, ən ðə dæɡɝ. mæt hæd tə hæv ðət dæɡɝ. fəɹ ðəɾ ɪf fəɹ nʌθɪŋ ɛls, hi hæd tə faɪn ðɛm. wʌt faɪnəli dɪsaɪɾɪd hɪm, hi wɑz əʃeɪm tə ɹilaɪz, wɑz ðəɾ i wɑz əfɹeɪd tə tʃɹaɪ əɡɛn. əfɹeɪd tə tʃɹaɪ tʃænəlɪŋ ðə paʊɝ. hi wɑz lɛs əfɹeɪɾ ə kənfɹʌntɪŋ dɑɹkfɹɛnz ən tʃɹɑləks wɪð oʊnli hʊɹɪn ən lɔɪəl ðən i wɑz ə ðæt.

Rand considered. If Fain and the Darkfriends were here - wherever here was - they might know how to get back. They had to, if they had reached here in the first place. And they had the Horn, and the dagger. Mat had to have that dagger. For that if for nothing else, he had to find them. What finally decided him, he was ashamed to realize, was that he was afraid to try again. Afraid to try channeling the Power. He was less afraid of confronting Darkfriends and Trollocs with only Hurin and Loial than he was of that.

"ðɛn wɪl ɡoʊ æftɝ ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz." hi tʃɹaɪd tə saʊnd ʃʊɹ, ðə weɪ læn wʊd, əɹ ɪŋtʃɹ. "ðə hɔɹn mʌs bi ɹəkʌvɝd. ɪf wi kæn pʌzəl aʊɾ ə weɪ tə teɪk ɪt fɹəm ðɛm, ət list wɪl noʊ wɛɹ ðeɪ ɑɹ wən wi faɪn ɪŋtʃɹ əɡɛn." ɪf oʊnli ðeɪ doʊn æsk haʊ wɝ gɑnə faɪn ɪm əɡɛn. "hʊɹɪn, meɪk ʃʊɹ ɪt ɹɪli ɪz ðə tʃɹeɪl wɝ æftɝ."

"Then we will go after the Darkfriends." He tried to sound sure, the way Lan would, or Ingtar. "The Horn must be recovered. If we can't puzzle out a way to take it from them, at least we will know where they are when we find Ingtar again." If only they don't ask how we're going to find him again. "Hurin, make sure it really is the trail we're after."

ðə snɪfɝ lɛpt ɪndə hɪz sæɾəl, iɡɝ tə bi duɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ hɪmsɛlf, pɝhæps iɡɝ tə bi əweɪ fɹəm ðə hɑloʊ, ən skɹæmbəld ɪz hɔɹs ʌp ðə bɹɔd, kʌlɝd stɛps. ði ænəməlz hʊvz ɹæŋ laʊdli ɑn ðə stoʊn, bʌt ðeɪ meɪd nɑɾ ə mɑɹk.

The sniffer leaped into his saddle, eager to be doing something himself, perhaps eager to be away from the hollow, and scrambled his horse up the broad, colored steps. The animal's hooves rang loudly on the stone, but they made not a mark.

ɹænd stoʊd ɹɛdz hɑbəlz ɪn ɪz sæɾəlbæɡz - ðə bænɝ wɑz stɪl ðɛɹ; hi wəd nɑɾ əv maɪndəɾ ɪf ðət hæd bɪn lɛf bɪhaɪnd - ðən ɡæðɝɾ ɪz baʊ ən kwɪvɝ ən klaɪm tə ðə stæljənz bæk. ðə bʌndəl ə tɑm mɛɹɪlɪnz kloʊk meɪɾ ə maʊn bɪhaɪn ɪz sæɾəl.

Rand stowed Red's hobbles in his saddlebags - the banner was still there; he would not have minded if that had been left behind - then gathered his bow and quiver and climbed to the stallion's back. The bundle of Thom Merrilin's cloak made a mound behind his saddle.

lɔɪəl lɛɾ ɪz bɪɡ maʊn oʊvɝ tə hɪm; wɪð ði oʊɡiɝ stændɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, lɔɪəlz hɛd keɪm ɔlmoʊs tə ɹændz ʃoʊldɝ, ən ɪm ɪn ɪz sæɾəl. lɔɪəl stɪl lʊk pʌzəld.

Loial led his big mount over to him; with the Ogier standing on the ground, Loial's head came almost to Rand's shoulder, and him in his saddle. Loial still looked puzzled.

"ju θɪŋk wi ʃəd steɪ hɪɹ?" ɹænd sɛd. "tʃɹaɪ əɡɛn tə juz ðə stoʊn? ɪf ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz ɑɹ hɪɹ, ɪn pleɪs, wɪv tə faɪn ðɛm. wi kæn liv ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ ɪn dɑɹkfɹɛn hænz; jə hɝd ði æmɪɝlɪn. ən wɪv tə ɡɛt ðət dæɡɝ bæk. mæt wɪl daɪ wɪθaʊɾ ɪt."

"You think we should stay here?" Rand said. "Try again to use the Stone? If the Darkfriends are here, in place, we have to find them. We can't leave the Horn of Valere in Darkfriend hands; you heard the Amyrlin. And we have to get that dagger back. Mat will die without it."

lɔɪəl nɑɾəd. "jɛs, ɹænd, wi du. bʌt, ɹænd, ðə stoʊnz. . . ."

Loial nodded. "Yes, Rand, we do. But, Rand, the Stones. . . ."

"wi wɪl faɪn ənʌðɝ. jə sɛd ðeɪ wɝ skæɾɝd ɔl oʊvɝ, ən ɪf ðəɹ ɔl laɪk ðɪs - ɔl ðɪs stoʊnwɝk ɝaʊn əm - ɪt ʃəd nɑt bi tu hɑɹd tə faɪnd wʌn."

"We will find another. You said they were scattered all over, and if they're all like this - all this stonework around them - it should not be too hard to find one."

"ɹænd, ðət fɹæɡmən sɛd ðə stoʊnz keɪm fɹəm ən oʊldɝ eɪdʒ ðən ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz, ən ivən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ðən dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ðɛm, ðoʊ ðeɪ juz ðɛm, səm ə ðə tʃɹuli paʊɝfəl dɪd. ðeɪ juzd əm wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ, ɹænd. haʊ dɪd jə θɪŋk tə juz ðɪs stoʊn tə teɪk əs bæk? əɹ ɛni ʌðɝ stoʊn wi faɪnd?"

"Rand, that fragment said the Stones came from an older Age than the Age of Legends, and even the Aes Sedai then did not understand them, though they used them, some of the truly powerful did. They used them with the One Power, Rand. How did you think to use this Stone to take us back? Or any other Stone we find?"

fəɹ ə moʊmən ɹænd kəɾ oʊnli stɛɹ ət ði oʊɡiɝ, θɪŋkɪŋ fæstɝ ðən i ɛvɝ hæɾ ɪn ɪz laɪf. "ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹ oʊldɝ ðən ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz, meɪbi ðə pipəl u bɪlt əm dɪdn juz ðə paʊɝ. ðəɹ mʌs bi ənʌðɝ weɪ. ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz ɡɑt hɪɹ, ən ðeɪ sɝɾənli kʊdn juz ðə paʊɝ. wʌtɛvɝ ðɪs ʌðɝ weɪ ɪz, əl faɪn ɪɾ aʊt. əl ɡɛɾ əs bæk, lɔɪəl." hi lʊkt ət ðə tɔl stoʊn kɑləm wɪð ɪts ɑd mɑɹkɪŋz, ən fɛlt ə pɹɪkəl ə fɪɹ. laɪt, ɪf oʊnli aɪ doʊn əv tə juz ðə paʊɝ tə də ɪt. "aɪ wɪl, lɔɪəl, aɪ pɹɑməs. wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ."

For a moment Rand could only stare at the Ogier, thinking faster than he ever had in his life. "If they are older than the Age of Legends, maybe the people who built them didn't use the Power. There must be another way. The Darkfriends got here, and they certainly couldn't use the Power. Whatever this other way is, I will find it out. I will get us back, Loial." He looked at the tall stone column with its odd markings, and felt a prickle of fear. Light, if only I don't have to use the Power to do it. "I will, Loial, I promise. One way or another."

ði oʊɡiɝ ɡeɪv ə daʊtfəl nɑd. hi swʌŋ ʌp ɑntu hɪz hjudʒ hɔɹs ən fɑloʊd ɹænd ʌp ðə stɛps tə dʒɔɪn hʊɹɪn əmʌŋ ðə blækən tʃɹiz.

The Ogier gave a doubtful nod. He swung up onto his huge horse and followed Rand up the steps to join Hurin among the blackened trees.

ðə læn stʃɹɛtʃt aʊt, loʊ ən ɹoʊlɪŋ, spɑɹsli fɔɹəstəd hɪɹ ən ðəɹ wɪð ɡɹæslæn bɪtwin, kɹɔs baɪ mɔɹ ðən wʌn stʃɹim. ɪn ðə mɪɾəl dɪstəns ɹænd θɔɾ i kəd si ənʌðɝ bɝn pætʃ. ɪt wɑz ɔl peɪl, ðə kʌlɝz wɑʃt. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ saɪn ʌv ɛniθɪŋ meɪd baɪ mɛn ɪksɛp ðə stoʊn sɝkəl bɪhaɪn ðɛm. ðə skaɪ wɑz ɛmpti, noʊ tʃɪmni smoʊk, noʊ bɝdz, oʊnli ə fju klaʊdz ən ðə peɪl jɛloʊ sʌn.

The land stretched out, low and rolling, sparsely forested here and there with grassland between, crossed by more than one stream. In the middle distance Rand thought he could see another burned patch. It was all pale, the colors washed. There was no sign of anything made by men except the stone circle behind them. The sky was empty, no chimney smoke, no birds, only a few clouds and the pale yellow sun.

wɝst ʌv ɔl, ðoʊ, ðə læn sim tə twɪs ði aɪ. wʌt wɑz kloʊs ət hæn lʊkt ɔl ɹaɪt, ən wʌt wɑz sin stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛɾ ɪn ðə dɪstəns. bʌt wɛnɛvɝ ɹænd tɝn ɪz hɛd, θɪŋz ðəɾ əpɪɹd dɪstənt wən sin fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz aɪ sim tə ɹʌʃ təwɔɹd hɪm, tə bi nɪɹɝ wən i stɛɹd stʃɹeɪɾ ət ðɛm. ɪt meɪd fəɹ dɪzinəs; ivən ðə hɔɹsəz wɪkɝd nɝvəsli ən ɹoʊl ðɛɹ aɪz. hi tʃɹaɪd muvɪŋ ɪz hɛd sloʊli; ði əpɛɹən muvmən ə θɪŋz ðət ʃʊɾə bɪn fɪkst wɑz stɪl ðɛɹ, bʌɾ ɪt sim tə hɛlp ə lɪɾəl.

Worst of all, though, the land seemed to twist the eye. What was close at hand looked all right, and what was seen straight ahead in the distance. But whenever Rand turned his head, things that appeared distant when seen from the corner of his eye seemed to rush toward him, to be nearer when he stared straight at them. It made for dizziness; even the horses whickered nervously and rolled their eyes. He tried moving his head slowly; the apparent movement of things that should have been fixed was still there, but it seemed to help a little.

"dɪd jəɹ pis ʌv ə bʊk seɪ ɛniθɪŋ əbaʊt ðɪs?" ɹænd æskt.

"Did your piece of a book say anything about this?" Rand asked.

lɔɪəl ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, ðən swɑloʊd hɑɹɾ əz ɪf i wɪʃt i hæd kɛpt ɪt stɪl. "nʌθɪŋ."

Loial shook his head, then swallowed hard as if he wished he had kept it still. "Nothing."

"aɪ səpoʊz ðɛɹz nʌθɪŋ tə də fəɹ ɪt. wɪtʃ weɪ, hʊɹɪn?"

"I suppose there's nothing to do for it. Which way, Hurin?"

"saʊθ, lɔɹd ɹænd." ðə snɪfɝ kɛpt ɪz aɪz ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd.

"South, Lord Rand." The sniffer kept his eyes on the ground.

"saʊθ, ðɛn." ðəɹ əz tə bi ə weɪ bæk bɪsaɪdz juzɪŋ ðə paʊɝ. ɹænd hild ɹɛdz flæŋks. hi tʃɹaɪd tə meɪk ɪz vɔɪs laɪthɑɹɾɪd, əz ɪf i sɔ noʊ dɪfəkəlti əɾ ɔl ɪn wʌt ðeɪ wɝ əbaʊt. "wʌt wɑz ɪɾ ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd? θɹi əɹ fɔɹ deɪz tə ðət mɑnjəmən tə ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ? aɪ wʌndɝ ɪf ðəɾ ɪɡzɪsts hɪɹ, tu, ðə weɪ ðə stoʊnz du. ɪf ðɪs ɪz ə wɝl ðət kəd bi, meɪbi ɪts stɪl stændɪŋ. wʊdn ðət bi sʌmθɪŋ tə si, lɔɪəl?"

"South, then." There has to be a way back besides using the Power. Rand heeled Red's flanks. He tried to make his voice lighthearted, as if he saw no difficulty at all in what they were about. "What was it Ingtar said? Three or four days to that monument to Artur Hawkwing? I wonder if that exists here, too, the way the Stones do. If this is a world that could be, maybe it's still standing. Wouldn't that be something to see, Loial?"

ðeɪ ɹoʊd saʊθ.

They rode south.


tʃæptɝ fɔɹtin


CHAPTER 14

wʊlfbɹəðɝ


Wolfbrother

"ɡɔn?" ɪŋtʃɹ dɪmændəɾ ə ði ɛɹ. "æn maɪ ɡɑɹdz sɔ nʌθɪŋ. nʌθɪŋ! ðeɪ kænɑt dʒʌs bi ɡɔn!"

"Gone?" Ingtar demanded of the air. "And my guards saw nothing. Nothing! They cannot just be gone!"

lɪsnɪŋ, pɛɹɪn hʌntʃt ɪz ʃoʊldɝz ən lʊkt ət mæt, hu stʊɾ ə lɪɾəl weɪ ɔf fɹaʊnɪŋ ən mʌɾɝɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf. ɑɹɡjuɪŋ wɪð hɪmsɛlf wɑz haʊ pɛɹɪn sɔ ɪt. ðə sʌn wɑz pikɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə hɝaɪzən, pæs taɪm fəɹ əm tə hæv bɪn ɹaɪɾɪŋ. ʃædoʊz leɪ lɔŋ əkɹɔs ðə hɑloʊ, stʃɹɛtʃt aʊɾ ən θɪnd, bʌt stɪl laɪk ðə tʃɹiz ðət meɪd ðɛm. ðə pækhɔɹsɪz, loʊɾəd ən ɑn ðɛɹ lɛd laɪn, stæmpt ɪmpeɪʃənli, bʌɾ ɛvɹiwʌn stʊd baɪ hɪz maʊn ən weɪɾəd.

Listening, Perrin hunched his shoulders and looked at Mat, who stood a little way off frowning and muttering to himself. Arguing with himself was how Perrin saw it. The sun was peeking over the horizon, past time for them to have been riding. Shadows lay long across the hollow, stretched out and thinned, but still like the trees that made them. The packhorses, loaded and on their lead line, stamped impatiently, but everyone stood by his mount and waited.

ənoʊ keɪm stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ ʌp. "nɑɾ ə ɡoʊt-kɪsɪŋ tʃɹæk, maɪ lɔɹd." hi saʊndəɾ əfɛndəd; feɪljɝ tʌtʃt ɑn ɪz skɪl. "bɝn mi, nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə fleɪmɪŋ huf skɹeɪp. ðeɪ dʒʌs blʌɾi vænɪʃt."

Uno came striding up. "Not a goat-kissing track, my Lord." He sounded offended; failure touched on his skill. "Burn me, not so much as a flaming hoof scrape. They just bloody vanished."

"θɹi mɛn ən θɹi hɔɹsəz də nɑt dʒʌs vænɪʃ," ɪŋtʃɹ ɡɹaʊld. "ɡoʊ oʊvɝ ðə ɡɹaʊn əɡɛn, ənoʊ. ɪf ɛniwʌn kən faɪnd wɛɹ ðeɪ wɛnt, ɪts ju."

"Three men and three horses do not just vanish," Ingtar growled. "Go over the ground again, Uno. If anyone can find where they went, it's you."

"meɪbi ðeɪ dʒʌst ɹæn əweɪ," mæt sɛd. ənoʊ stɑpt ən ɡlɛɹɾ ət hɪm. laɪk hid kɝst ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, pɛɹɪn θɔt wʌndɝɪŋli.

"Maybe they just ran away," Mat said. Uno stopped and glared at him. Like he'd cursed an Aes Sedai, Perrin thought wonderingly.

"waɪ wəd ðeɪ ɹʌn əweɪ?" ɪŋtʃɹz vɔɪs wɑz deɪnʒɝəsli sɑft. "ɹænd, ðə bɪldɝ, maɪ snɪfɝ - maɪ snɪfɝ! - waɪ wəɾ ɛni ʌv əm ɹʌn, mʌtʃ lɛs ɔl θɹi?"

"Why would they run away?" Ingtar's voice was dangerously soft. "Rand, the Builder, my sniffer - my sniffer! - why would any of them run, much less all three?"

mæt ʃɹʌɡd. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ. ɹænd wɑz. . . ." pɛɹɪn wɑntəd tə θɹoʊ sʌmθɪŋ ət hɪm, hɪt hɪm, ɛniθɪŋ tə stɑp hɪm, bʌɾ ɪŋtʃɹ ən ənoʊ wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ. hi fɛlt ə flʌɾ ə ɹɪlif wən mæt hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən spɹɛɾ ɪz hænz ən mʌɾɝd, "aɪ doʊnt noʊ waɪ. aɪ dʒʌs θɔt meɪbi ðeɪ hæd."

Mat shrugged. "I don't know. Rand was. . . ." Perrin wanted to throw something at him, hit him, anything to stop him, but Ingtar and Uno were watching. He felt a flood of relief when Mat hesitated, then spread his hands and muttered, "I don't know why. I just thought maybe they had."

ɪŋtʃɹ ɡɹɪməst. "ɹæn əweɪ," hi ɡɹaʊld əz ɪf i dɪd nɑt bɪliv ɪt fəɹ ən ɪnstənt. "ðə bɪldɝ kən ɡoʊ əz i wɪl, bʌt hʊɹɪn wəd nɑt ɹʌn əweɪ. ən niðɝ wəd ɹænd ælθɹ. hi wəd nɑt; hi noʊz ɪz duɾi, naʊ. ɡoʊ ɑn, ənoʊ. sɝtʃ ðə ɡɹaʊn əɡɛn." ənoʊ ɡeɪv ə hæf baʊ ən hɝiɾ əweɪ, sɔɹd hɪl bɑbɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. ɪŋtʃɹ ɡɹʌmbəld, "waɪ wəd hʊɹɪn liv laɪk ðæt, ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə naɪt, wɪθaʊɾ ə wɝd? hi noʊz wʌt wɝ əbaʊt. haʊ æm aɪ tə tʃɹæk ðɪs ʃædoʊ-spɔn fɪlθ wɪθaʊt hɪm? aɪ wəd ɡɪv ə θaʊzənd ɡoʊl kɹaʊnz fəɹ ə pæk ə tʃɹeɪl haʊnz. ɪf aɪ dɪd nɑt noʊ bɛɾɝ, aɪ wəd seɪ ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz mænədʒ ðɪs soʊ ðeɪ kən slɪp ist əɹ wɛst wɪθaʊt mi noʊɪŋ. pis, aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɪf aɪ də noʊ bɛɾɝ." hi stʌmpt ɔf æftɝ ənoʊ.

Ingtar grimaced. "Ran away," he growled as if he did not believe it for an instant. "The Builder can go as he will, but Hurin would not run away. And neither would Rand al'Thor. He would not; he knows his duty, now. Go on, Uno. Search the ground again." Uno gave a half bow and hurried away, sword hilt bobbing over his shoulder. Ingtar grumbled, "Why would Hurin leave like that, in the middle of the night, without a word? He knows what we're about. How am I to track this Shadow-spawned filth without him? I would give a thousand gold crowns for a pack of trail hounds. If I did not know better, I would say the Darkfriends managed this so they can slip east or west without me knowing. Peace, I don't know if I do know better." He stumped off after Uno.

pɛɹɪn ʃɪftəɾ ənizəli. ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz wɝ daʊtləs ɡɛɾɪŋ fɝðɝ əweɪ wɪð ɛvɹi mɪnət. ɡɛɾɪŋ fɝðɝ əweɪ, ən wɪð əm ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ - ən ðə dæɡɝ fɹəm ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ. hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ðət ɹænd, wʌtɛvɝ i hæd bɪkʌm, wʌtɛvɝ hæd hæpən tə hɪm, wəɾ əbændən ðət tʃeɪs. bʌt wɛɹ dɪɾ i ɡoʊ, ən waɪ? lɔɪəl maɪt ɡoʊ wɪð ɹænd fəɹ fɹɛndʃɪp - bʌt waɪ hʊɹɪn?

Perrin shifted uneasily. The Darkfriends were doubtless getting further away with every minute. Getting further away, and with them the Horn of Valere - and the dagger from Shadar Logoth. He did not think that Rand, whatever he had become, whatever had happened to him, would abandon that chase. But where did he go, and why? Loial might go with Rand for friendship - but why Hurin?

"meɪbi hi dɪd ɹʌn əweɪ," hi mʌɾɝd, ðən lʊkt ɝaʊnd. noʊ wʌn əpɪɹd tə hæv hɝd; ivən mæt wɑz nɑt peɪɪŋ ɪm ɛni maɪnd. hi skɹʌbd ə hæn θɹu hɪz hɛɹ. ɪf ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd bɪn æftɝ ɪm tə bi ə fɔls dʒɹæɡən, hi wəɾ əv ɹʌn, tu. bʌt wɝiɪŋ əbaʊt ɹænd wɑz duɪŋ nʌθɪŋ tə hɛlp tʃɹæk ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz.

"Maybe he did run away," he muttered, then looked around. No one appeared to have heard; even Mat was not paying him any mind. He scrubbed a hand through his hair. If Aes Sedai had been after him to be a false Dragon, he would have run, too. But worrying about Rand was doing nothing to help track the Darkfriends.

ðəɹ wɑz ə weɪ, pɝhæps, ɪf i wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə teɪk ɪt. hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə teɪk ɪt. hi hæd bɪn ɹʌnɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ɪt, bʌt pɝhæps, naʊ, hi kəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɹʌn. sɝvz mi ɹaɪt fəɹ wʌɾ aɪ toʊld ɹænd. aɪ wɪʃ aɪ kəd ɹʌn. ivən noʊɪŋ wʌɾ i kəd də tə hɛlp - wʌɾ i hæd tə də - hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd.

There was a way, perhaps, if he was willing to take it. He did not want to take it. He had been running away from it, but perhaps, now, he could no longer run. Serves me right for what I told Rand. I wish I could run. Even knowing what he could do to help - what he had to do - he hesitated.

noʊ wʌn wɑz lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm. noʊ wʌn wəd noʊ wʌt ðeɪ wɝ siɪŋ ivən ɪf ðeɪ dɪd lʊk. faɪnəli, ɹɪlʌktənli, hi kloʊzd ɪz aɪz ən lɛt hɪmsɛlf dʒɹɪft, lɛɾ ɪz θɔts dʒɹɪft, aʊt, əweɪ fɹəm hɪm.

No one was looking at him. No one would know what they were seeing even if they did look. Finally, reluctantly, he closed his eyes and let himself drift, let his thoughts drift, out, away from him.

hi hæd tʃɹaɪd dɪnaɪɪŋ ɪt fɹəm ðə fɝst, lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ɪz aɪz bɪɡæn tə tʃeɪnʒ fɹəm dɑɹk bɹaʊn tə bɝnɪʃt ɡoʊldən jɛloʊ. ət ðət fɝs miɾɪŋ, ðət fɝst ɪnstən ə ɹɛkəɡnɪʃən, hi hæd ɹəfjuz tə bɪliv, ən i hæd ɹʌn fɹəm ðə ɹɛkəɡnɪʃən ɛvɝ sɪns. hi stɪl wɑntəd tə ɹʌn.

He had tried denying it from the first, long before his eyes began to change from dark brown to burnished golden yellow. At that first meeting, that first instant of recognition, he had refused to believe, and he had run from the recognition ever since. He still wanted to run.

hɪz θɔts dʒɹɪftəd, filɪŋ fəɹ wʌt mʌs bi aʊt ðɛɹ, wʌt wɑz ɔlweɪz aʊt ðəɹ ɪn kʌntʃɹi wɛɹ mɛn wɝ fju əɹ fɑɹ bɪtwin, filɪŋ fəɹ ɪz bɹʌðɝz. hi dɪd nɑt laɪk tə θɪŋk ə ðɛm ðət weɪ, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ.

His thoughts drifted, feeling for what must be out there, what was always out there in country where men were few or far between, feeling for his brothers. He did not like to think of them that way, but they were.

ɪn ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ i hæd bɪn əfɹeɪd ðət wʌɾ i dɪd hæd səm teɪn ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn, əɹ ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ - ikwəli bæd fəɹ ə mæn u wɑntəd nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ ðən tə bi ə blæksmɪθ ən lɪv ɪz laɪf ɪn ðə laɪt, ən ɪn pis. fɹəm ðət taɪm, hi nu sʌmθɪŋ ə haʊ ɹænd fɛlt, əfɹeɪɾ ə hɪmsɛlf, filɪŋ ənklin. hi wɑz stɪl nɑt pæs ðəɾ ɪntaɪɝli. ðɪs θɪŋ i dɪd wɑz oʊldɝ ðən hjumənz juzɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ, ðoʊ, sʌmθɪŋ fɹəm ðə bɝθ ə taɪm. nɑt ðə paʊɝ, mɔɪɹeɪn hæd toʊl hɪm. sʌmθɪŋ lɔŋ vænɪʃt, naʊ kʌm əɡɛn. ɛɡwin nu, tu, ðoʊ hi wɪʃt ʃi dɪd nɑt. hi wɪʃt noʊ wʌn dɪd. hi hoʊpt ʃi hæd nɑt toʊld ɛniwʌn.

In the beginning he had been afraid that what he did had some taint of the Dark One, or of the One Power - equally bad for a man who wanted nothing more than to be a blacksmith and live his life in the Light, and in peace. From that time, he knew something of how Rand felt, afraid of himself, feeling unclean. He was still not past that entirely. This thing he did was older than humans using the One Power, though, something from the birth of Time. Not the Power, Moiraine had told him. Something long vanished, now come again. Egwene knew, too, though he wished she did not. He wished no one did. He hoped she had not told anyone.

kɑntækt. hi fɛl ðɛm, fɛlt ʌðɝ maɪnz. fɛlt ɪz bɹʌðɝz, ðə wʊlvz.

Contact. He felt them, felt other minds. Felt his brothers, the wolves.

ðɛɹ θɔts keɪm tə hɪm əz ə wɝlpul blɛn ʌv ɪmədʒəz ən ɪmoʊʃənz. ət fɝst i hæd nɑt bɪn eɪbəl tə meɪk aʊɾ ɛniθɪŋ ɪksɛp ðə ɹɔ ɪmoʊʃən, bʌt naʊ hɪz maɪn pʊt wɝdz tə ðɛm. wʊlfbɹəðɝ. sɝpɹaɪz. tu-lɛɡz ðət tɔks. ə feɪɾəd ɪmədʒ, dɪm wɪð taɪm, oʊl bɪɑn oʊld, ʌv mɛn ɹʌnɪŋ wɪð wʊlvz, tu pæks hʌntɪŋ təɡɛðɝ. wɪv hɝd ðɪs kʌmz əɡɛn. jə ɑɹ lɔŋ tuθ?

Their thoughts came to him as a whirlpool blend of images and emotions. At first he had not been able to make out anything except the raw emotion, but now his mind put words to them. Wolfbrother. Surprise. Two-legs that talks. A faded image, dim with time, old beyond old, of men running with wolves, two packs hunting together. We have heard this comes again. You are Long Tooth?

ɪt wɑz ə feɪn pɪktʃɝ ʌv ə mæn dʒɹɛst ɪn kloʊðz meɪɾ ə haɪdz, wɪð ə lɔŋ naɪf ɪn ɪz hænd, bʌɾ oʊvɝleɪɾ ɑn ði ɪmədʒ, mɔɹ sɛntʃɹəl, wɑz ə ʃæɡi wʊlf wɪð wʌn tuθ lɔŋɡɝ ðən ðə ɹɛst, ə stil tuθ ɡlimɪŋ ɪn ðə sʌnlaɪɾ əz ðə wʊlf lɛd ðə pæk ɪn ə dɛspɹɪt tʃɑɹdʒ θɹu dip snoʊ təwɔɹd ðə dɪɹ ðət wəd min laɪf ɪnstɛɾ ə sloʊ dɛθ baɪ stɑɹveɪʃən, ən ðə dɪɹ θɹæʃɪŋ tə ɹʌn ɪn paʊɾɝ tə ðɛɹ bɛliz, ən ðə sʌn ɡlɪntɪŋ ɑn ðə waɪɾ əntɪl ɪt hɝt ði aɪz, ən ðə wɪn haʊlɪŋ daʊn ðə pæsəz, swɝlɪŋ ðə faɪn snoʊ laɪk mɪst, ænd. . . . wʊlvz' neɪmz wɝ ɔlweɪz kɑmplɛks ɪmədʒəz.

It was a faint picture of a man dressed in clothes made of hides, with a long knife in his hand, but overlaid on the image, more central, was a shaggy wolf with one tooth longer than the rest, a steel tooth gleaming in the sunlight as the wolf led the pack in a desperate charge through deep snow toward the deer that would mean life instead of slow death by starvation, and the deer thrashing to run in powder to their bellies, and the sun glinting on the white until it hurt the eyes, and the wind howling down the passes, swirling the fine snow like mist, and. . . . Wolves' names were always complex images.

pɛɹɪn ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə mæn. ɛlaɪəs mækɛɹə, hu hæd fɝst ɪntʃɹədust ɪm tə wʊlvz. səmtaɪmz i wɪʃt i hæd nɛvɝ mɛɾ ɛlaɪəs.

Perrin recognized the man. Elyas Machera, who had first introduced him to wolves. Sometimes he wished he had never met Elyas.

noʊ, hi θɔt, ən tʃɹaɪd tə pɪktʃɝ hɪmsɛlf ɪn ɪz maɪnd.

No, he thought, and tried to picture himself in his mind.

jɛs. wɪv hɝɾ ə ju.

Yes. We have heard of you.

ɪt wɑz nɑt ði ɪmədʒ i hæd meɪd, ə jʌŋ mæn wɪð hɛvi ʃoʊldɝz ən ʃæɡi, bɹaʊn kɝlz, ə jʌŋ mæn wɪð ən æks əɾ ɪz bɛlt, hu ʌðɝz θɔt muvd ən θɔt sloʊli. ðət mæn wɑz ðɛɹ, sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ðə maɪn pɪktʃɝ ðət keɪm fɹəm ðə wʊlvz, bʌt stʃɹɔŋɝ baɪ fɑɹ wɑz ə mæsɪv, waɪl bʊl wɪð kɝv hɔɹnz ə ʃaɪnɪŋ mɛɾəl, ɹʌnɪŋ θɹu ðə naɪt wɪð ðə spiɾ ən ɪɡzubɝəns ə juθ, kɝli-hɛɹd koʊt ɡlimɪŋ ɪn ðə munlaɪt, flɪŋɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ɪn əmʌŋ waɪtkloʊks ɑn ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz, wɪð ði ɛɹ kɹɪsp ən koʊld ən dɑɹk, ən blʌd soʊ ɹɛɾ ɑn ðə hɔɹnz, ænd. . . .

It was not the image he had made, a young man with heavy shoulders and shaggy, brown curls, a young man with an axe at his belt, who others thought moved and thought slowly. That man was there, somewhere in the mind picture that came from the wolves, but stronger by far was a massive, wild bull with curved horns of shining metal, running through the night with the speed and exuberance of youth, curly-haired coat gleaming in the moonlight, flinging himself in among Whitecloaks on their horses, with the air crisp and cold and dark, and blood so red on the horns, and. . . .

jʌŋ bʊl.

Young Bull.

fəɹ ə moʊmən pɛɹɪn lɔs ðə kɑntækt ɪn ɪz ʃɑk. hi hæd nɑt dʒɹim ðeɪ hæd ɡɪvən ɪm ə neɪm. hi wɪʃt i kəd nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ haʊ hi hæɾ ɝn ɪt. hi tʌtʃt ði æks əɾ ɪz bɛlt, wɪð ɪts ɡlimɪŋ, hæf-mun bleɪd. laɪt hɛlp mi, aɪ kɪl tu mɛn. ðeɪ wʊɾə kɪl mi ivən kwɪkɝ, ən ɛɡwin, bʌt. . . .

For a moment Perrin lost the contact in his shock. He had not dreamed they had given him a name. He wished he could not remember how he had earned it. He touched the axe at his belt, with its gleaming, half-moon blade. Light help me, I killed two men. They would have killed me even quicker, and Egwene, but. . . .

pʊʃɪŋ ɔl ðəɾ əsaɪd - ɪt wɑz dʌn ən bɪhaɪn hɪm; hi hæd noʊ wɪʃ tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɛni ʌv ɪt - hi ɡeɪv ðə wʊlvz ðə smɛl ə ɹænd, ʌv lɔɪəl ən hʊɹɪn, ən æskt ɪf ðeɪ hæd sɛntɪd ðə θɹi. ɪt wɑz wʌn ə ðə θɪŋz ðət hæd kʌm tə hɪm wɪð ðə tʃeɪnʒ ɪn ɪz aɪz; hi kəɾ aɪdɛntəfaɪ pipəl baɪ ðɛɹ smɛl ivən wən i kəd nɑt si ðɛm. hi kəd si mɔɹ ʃɑɹpli, tu, si ɪn ɛniθɪŋ bʌt pɪtʃ-dɑɹknəs. hi wɑz ɔlweɪz kɛɹfəl tə laɪt læmps əɹ kændəlz, naʊ, səmtaɪmz bɪfɔɹ ɛniwʌn ɛls θɔt ðeɪ wɝ niɾəd.

Pushing all that aside - it was done and behind him; he had no wish to remember any of it - he gave the wolves the smell of Rand, of Loial and Hurin, and asked if they had scented the three. It was one of the things that had come to him with the change in his eyes; he could identify people by their smell even when he could not see them. He could see more sharply, too, see in anything but pitch-darkness. He was always careful to light lamps or candles, now, sometimes before anyone else thought they were needed.

fɹəm ðə wʊlvz keɪm ə vju ʌv mɛn ɑn hɔɹsəz əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ ðə hɑloʊ ɪn leɪt deɪ. ðət wɑz ðə læs ðeɪ hæd sin əɹ smɛld ə ɹænd əɹ ði ʌðɝ tu.

From the wolves came a view of men on horses approaching the hollow in late day. That was the last they had seen or smelled of Rand or the other two.

pɛɹɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. ðə nɛkst stɛp wəd bi jusləs ənlɛs i toʊld ɪŋtʃɹ. ən mæt wɪl daɪ ɪf wi doʊn faɪn ðət dæɡɝ. bɝn ju, ɹænd, waɪ dɪd jə teɪk ðə snɪfɝ?

Perrin hesitated. The next step would be useless unless he told Ingtar. And Mat will die if we don't find that dagger. Burn you, Rand, why did you take the sniffer?

ðə wʌn taɪm i hæd ɡɔn tə ðə dʌnʒən, wɪð ɛɡwin, ðə smɛl ə feɪn hæd meɪɾ ɪz hɛɹ stæn ɑn ɛnd; nɑɾ ivən tʃɹɑləks smɛl soʊ faʊl. hi hæd wɑntəd tə ɹɪp θɹu ðə bɑɹz ə ðə sɛl ən tɛɹ ðə mæn əpɑɹt, ən faɪndɪŋ ðəɾ ɪnsaɪd hɪmsɛlf hæd fɹaɪɾənd ɪm mɔɹ ðən feɪn dɪd. tə mæsk feɪnz smɛl ɪn ɪz oʊn maɪnd, hi æɾəd ðə sɛn ə tʃɹɑləks bɪfɔɹ i haʊld əlaʊd.

The one time he had gone to the dungeon, with Egwene, the smell of Fain had made his hair stand on end; not even Trollocs smelled so foul. He had wanted to rip through the bars of the cell and tear the man apart, and finding that inside himself had frightened him more than Fain did. To mask Fain's smell in his own mind, he added the scent of Trollocs before he howled aloud.

fɹəm ðə dɪstəns keɪm ðə kɹaɪz ʌv ə wʊlfpæk, ən ɪn ðə hɑloʊ hɔɹsəz stæmpt ən wɪkɝd fɪɹfəli. səm ə ðə soʊlʒɝz fɪŋɡɝd ðɛɹ lɔŋ-bleɪɾɪd lænsɪz ən aɪd ðə ɹɪm ə ðə hɑloʊ ənizəli. ɪnsaɪd pɛɹɪnz hɛd, ɪt wɑz mʌtʃ wɝs. hi fɛl ðə ɹeɪdʒ ə ðə wʊlvz, ðə heɪt. ðəɹ wɝ oʊnli tu θɪŋz wʊlvz heɪɾəd. ɔl ɛls ðeɪ mɪɹli ɛndʒjʊɹd, bʌt faɪɝ ən tʃɹɑləks ðeɪ heɪɾəd, ən ðeɪ wəd ɡoʊ θɹu faɪɝ tə kɪl tʃɹɑləks.

From the distance came the cries of a wolfpack, and in the hollow horses stamped and whickered fearfully. Some of the soldiers fingered their long-bladed lances and eyed the rim of the hollow uneasily. Inside Perrin's head, it was much worse. He felt the rage of the wolves, the hate. There were only two things wolves hated. All else they merely endured, but fire and Trollocs they hated, and they would go through fire to kill Trollocs.

ivən mɔɹ ðən ðə tʃɹɑləks, feɪnz sɛn hæd pʊɾ əm ɪndə ə fɹɛnzi, əz ɪf ðeɪ smɛl sʌmθɪŋ ðət meɪd tʃɹɑləks sim nætʃɹəl ən ɹaɪt.

Even more than the Trollocs, Fain's scent had put them into a frenzy, as if they smelled something that made Trollocs seem natural and right.

wɛɹ?

Where?

ðə skaɪ ɹoʊld ɪn ɪz hɛd; ðə læn spʌn. ist ən wɛst, wʊlvz dɪd nɑt noʊ. ðeɪ nu ðə muvməns ə sʌn ən mun, ðə ʃɪft ə sizənz, ðə kɑntʊɹz ə ðə lænd. pɛɹɪn pʌzəld ɪɾ aʊt. saʊθ. ən sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ. ən iɡɝnəs tə kɪl ðə tʃɹɑləks. ðə wʊlvz wəd lɛt jʌŋ bʊl ʃɛɹ ɪn ðə kɪlɪŋ. hi kəd bɹɪŋ ðə tu-lɛɡz wɪð ðɛɹ hɑɹd skɪnz ɪf i wɑntəd, bʌt jʌŋ bʊl, ən smoʊk, ən tu dɪɹ, ən wɪntɝ dɔn, ən ɔl ðə ɹɛst ə ðə pæk wəd hʌn daʊn ðə twɪstəd wʌnz u hæd dɛɹd kʌm ɪndə ðɛɹ lænd. ði ɪnɛɾəbəl flɛʃ ən bɪɾɝ blʌd wəd bɝn ðə tʌŋ, bʌt ðeɪ mʌs bi kɪld. kɪl ðɛm. kɪl ðə twɪstəd wʌnz.

The sky rolled in his head; the land spun. East and west, wolves did not know. They knew the movements of sun and moon, the shift of seasons, the contours of the land. Perrin puzzled it out. South. And something more. An eagerness to kill the Trollocs. The wolves would let Young Bull share in the killing. He could bring the two-legs with their hard skins if he wanted, but Young Bull, and Smoke, and Two Deer, and Winter Dawn, and all the rest of the pack would hunt down the Twisted Ones who had dared come into their land. The inedible flesh and bitter blood would burn the tongue, but they must be killed. Kill them. Kill the Twisted Ones.

ðɛɹ fjʊɹi ɪnfɛktəd hɪm. hɪz lɪps pil bæk ɪn ə snɑɹl, ən i tʊk ə stɛp, tə dʒɔɪn ðɛm, ɹʌn wɪð əm ɪn ðə hʌnt, ɪn ðə kɪlɪŋ.

Their fury infected him. His lips peeled back in a snarl, and he took a step, to join them, run with them in the hunt, in the killing.

wɪð ən ɛfɝɾ i bɹoʊk ðə kɑntækt ɪksɛp fəɹ ə θɪn sɛns ðət ðə wʊlvz wɝ ðɛɹ. hi cʊɾə pɔɪntəd tə ðɛm əkɹɔs ði ɪntɝvinɪŋ dɪstəns. hi fɛl koʊld ɪnsaɪd. ɪm ə mæn, nɑɾ ə wʊlf. laɪt hɛlp mi, aɪm ə mæn!

With an effort he broke the contact except for a thin sense that the wolves were there. He could have pointed to them across the intervening distance. He felt cold inside. I'm a man, not a wolf. Light help me, I am a man!

"ɑɹ jə wɛl, pɛɹɪn?" mæt sɛd, muvɪŋ kloʊsɝ. hi saʊndəd ðə weɪ hi ɔlweɪz dɪd, flɪpənt - ən bɪɾɝ ʌndɝ ɪt, tu, ʌv leɪt - bʌɾ i lʊkt wɝid. "ðæɾ ɪz ɔl aɪ nid. ɹænd ɹʌn ɔf, ən ðən jə ɡɛt sɪk. aɪ doʊnt noʊ wɛɹ əl faɪn ə wɪzdəm tə lʊk æftɝ jə aʊt hɪɹ. aɪ θɪŋk aɪ hæv səm wɪloʊbɑɹk ɪn maɪ sæɾəlbæɡz. aɪ kən meɪk jə səm wɪloʊbɑɹk ti, ɪf ɪŋtʃɹ lɛts əs steɪ ðət lɔŋ. sɝv jə ɹaɪɾ ɪf aɪ meɪk ɪt tu stʃɹɔŋ."

"Are you well, Perrin?" Mat said, moving closer. He sounded the way he always did, flippant - and bitter under it, too, of late - but he looked worried. "That is all I need. Rand run off, and then you get sick. I don't know where I'll find a Wisdom to look after you out here. I think I have some willowbark in my saddlebags. I can make you some willowbark tea, if Ingtar lets us stay that long. Serve you right if I make it too strong."

"aɪ . . . ɪm ɔl ɹaɪt, mæt." ʃeɪkɪŋ ɔf ɪz fɹɛnd, hi wɛn tə faɪn ɪŋtʃɹ. ðə ʃaɪnɝən lɔɹd wɑz skænɪŋ ðə ɡɹaʊn ɑn ðə ɹɪm wɪð ənoʊ, ən ɹeɪɡən, ən mæsimə. ði ʌðɝz fɹaʊn əɾ ɪm əz i dʒɹu ɪŋtʃɹ əsaɪd. hi meɪd ʃʊɹ ənoʊ ən ðə ɹɛst wɝ tu fɑɹ əweɪ tə hɪɹ bɪfɔɹ i spoʊk. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ wɛɹ ɹænd əɹ ði ʌðɝz wɛnt, ɪŋtʃɹ, bʌt pdən feɪn ən ðə tʃɹɑləks - ən aɪ ɡɛs ðə ɹɛst ə ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz - ɑɹ stɪl hɛɾɪŋ saʊθ."

"I . . . I'm all right, Mat." Shaking off his friend, he went to find Ingtar. The Shienaran lord was scanning the ground on the rim with Uno, and Ragan, and Masema. The others frowned at him as he drew Ingtar aside. He made sure Uno and the rest were too far away to hear before he spoke. "I don't know where Rand or the others went, Ingtar, but Padan Fain and the Trollocs - and I guess the rest of the Darkfriends - are still heading south."

"haʊ dʒju noʊ ðɪs?" ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd.

"How do you know this?" Ingtar said.

pɛɹɪn dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ. "wʊlvz toʊl mi." hi weɪɾəd, fəɹ wʌɾ i wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ. læftɝ, skɔɹn, ən ækjəzeɪʃən ə biɪŋ ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd, ʌv biɪŋ mæd. dɪlɪbɝətli, hi tʌkt ɪz θʌmz bɪhaɪn ɪz bɛlt, əweɪ fɹəm ði æks. əl nɑt kɪl. nɑɾ əɡɛn. ɪf i tʃɹaɪz tə kɪl mi fəɹ ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd, əl ɹʌn, bʌɾ aɪ woʊn kɪl ɛnibəɾi ɛls.

Perrin drew a deep breath. "Wolves told me." He waited, for what he was not sure. Laughter, scorn, an accusation of being a Darkfriend, of being mad. Deliberately, he tucked his thumbs behind his belt, away from the axe. I will not kill. Not again. If he tries to kill me for a Darkfriend, I'll run, but I won't kill anybody else.

"aɪ hæv hɝɾ ə θɪŋz laɪk ðɪs," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd sloʊli, æftɝ ə moʊmənt. "ɹumɝz. ðəɹ wɑz ə wɔɹɾɝ, ə mæn kɔld ɛlaɪəs mækɛɹə, hu səm sɛd kəd tɔk tə wʊlvz. hi dɪsəpɪɹd jɪɹz əɡoʊ." hi sim tə kætʃ sʌmθɪŋ ɪn pɛɹɪnz aɪz. "ju noʊ hɪm?"

"I have heard of things like this," Ingtar said slowly, after a moment. "Rumors. There was a Warder, a man called Elyas Machera, who some said could talk to wolves. He disappeared years ago." He seemed to catch something in Perrin's eyes. "You know him?"

"aɪ noʊ hɪm," pɛɹɪn sɛd flætli. "hiz ðə wʌn. . . . aɪ doʊnt wɑnə tɔk əbaʊɾ ɪt. aɪ dɪdn æsk fəɹ ɪt." ðæts wʌt ɹænd sɛd. laɪt, aɪ wɪʃ aɪ wɝ hoʊm wɝkɪŋ mæstɝ luhənz fɔɹdʒ.

"I know him," Perrin said flatly. "He's the one. . . . I don't want to talk about it. I didn't ask for it." That's what Rand said. Light, I wish I were home working Master Luhhan's forge.

"ðiz wʊlvz," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd, "ðeɪ wɪl tʃɹæk ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz ən tʃɹɑləks fəɹ ʌs?" pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd. "ɡʊd. əl əv ðə hɔɹn, wʌtɛvɝ ɪt teɪks." ðə ʃaɪnɝən ɡlænst ɝaʊn əɾ ənoʊ ən ði ʌðɝz stɪl sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ tʃɹæks. "bɛɾɝ nɑt tə tɛl ɛniwʌn ɛls, ðoʊ. wʊlvz ɑɹ kənsɪɾɝd ɡʊd lʌk ɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz. tʃɹɑləks fɪɹ ðɛm. bʌt stɪl, bɛɾɝ tə kip ðɪs bɪtwin əs fəɹ ðə taɪm. səm ə ðɛm maɪt nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd."

"These wolves," Ingtar said, "they will track the Darkfriends and Trollocs for us?" Perrin nodded. "Good. I will have the Horn, whatever it takes." The Shienaran glanced around at Uno and the others still searching for tracks. "Better not to tell anyone else, though. Wolves are considered good luck in the Borderlands. Trollocs fear them. But still, better to keep this between us for the time. Some of them might not understand."

"aɪ wəɾ əz sun noʊbɑdi ɛls ɛvɝ faʊn aʊt," pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"I would as soon nobody else ever found out," Perrin said.

"aɪ wɪl tɛl əm jə θɪŋk juv hʊɹɪnz tælənt. ðeɪ noʊ əbaʊt ðæt; ðəɹ izi wɪð ɪt. səm ə ðɛm sɔ jə ɹɪŋkəlɪŋ jəɹ noʊz bæk ɪn ðət vɪlədʒ, ən ət ðə fɛɹi. aɪv hɝd dʒoʊks əbaʊt jəɹ dɛləkət noʊz. jɛs. jə kip əs ɑn ðə tʃɹeɪl tədeɪ, ənoʊ wɪl si ɪnʌf ə ðɛɹ tʃɹæks tə kənfɝm ɪts ðə tʃɹeɪl, ən bɪfɔɹ naɪtfɔl ɛvɹi læs mæn wɪl bi ʃʊɹ jə ɑɹ ə snɪfɝ. əl əv ðə hɔɹn." hi ɡlænst ət ðə skaɪ, ən ɹeɪzd ɪz vɔɪs. "deɪlaɪɾ ɪz weɪstɪŋ! tə hɔɹs!"

"I will tell them you think you have Hurin's talent. They know about that; they're easy with it. Some of them saw you wrinkling your nose back in that village, and at the ferry. I've heard jokes about your delicate nose. Yes. You keep us on the trail today, Uno will see enough of their tracks to confirm it is the trail, and before nightfall every last man will be sure you are a sniffer. I will have the Horn." He glanced at the sky, and raised his voice. "Daylight is wasting! To horse!"

tə pɛɹɪnz sɝpɹaɪz, ðə ʃaɪnɝənz sim tə æksɛpt ɪŋtʃɹz stɔɹi. ə fju ʌv əm lʊk skɛptəkəl - mæsimə wɛn soʊ fɑɹ əz tə spɪt - bʌɾ ənoʊ nɑɾəd θɔtfəli, ən ðət wɑz ɪnʌf fəɹ moʊst. mæt wɑz ðə hɑɹɾəst tə kənvɪns.

To Perrin's surprise, the Shienarans seemed to accept Ingtar's story. A few of them looked skeptical - Masema went so far as to spit - but Uno nodded thoughtfully, and that was enough for most. Mat was the hardest to convince.

"ə snɪfɝ! ju? jəɹ gɑnə tʃɹæk mɝɾɝɝz baɪ smɛl? pɛɹɪn, jə ɑɹ əz kɹeɪzi əz ɹænd. aɪm ði oʊnli seɪn wʌn lɛft fɹəm ɛmənz fild, wɪð ɛɡwin ən nɪneɪiv tʃɹɑɾɪŋ ɔf tə tɑɹ vəlɑn tə bɪkʌm - " hi kʌt hɪmsɛlf ʃɔɹt wɪð ən ənizi ɡlæns fəɹ ðə ʃaɪnɝənz.

"A sniffer! You? You're going to track murderers by smell? Perrin, you are as crazy as Rand. I am the only sane one left from Emond's Field, with Egwene and Nynaeve trotting off to Tar Valon to become - " He cut himself short with an uneasy glance for the Shienarans.

pɛɹɪn tʊk hʊɹɪnz pleɪs bɪsaɪɾ ɪŋtʃɹ əz ðə smɔl kɑləm ɹoʊd saʊθ. mæt kɛpt ʌp ə stʃɹɪŋ ə dɪspɛɹɪdʒɪŋ ɹɪmɑɹks, əntɪl ənoʊ faʊn ðə fɝs tʃɹæks lɛf baɪ tʃɹɑləks ən baɪ mɛn ɑn hɔɹsəz, bʌt pɛɹɪn peɪɾ ɪm lɪɾəl maɪnd. ɪt wɑz ɔl i kəd də tə kip ðə wʊlvz fɹəm dæʃɪŋ ɑn əhɛd tə kɪl ðə tʃɹɑləks. ðə wʊlvz kɛɹɾ oʊnli əbaʊt kɪlɪŋ ðə twɪstəd wʌnz; tə ðɛm, dɑɹkfɹɛnz wɝ noʊ dɪfɹən fɹəm ɛni ʌðɝ tu-lɛɡz. pɛɹɪn kəɾ ɔlmoʊst si ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz skæɾɝɪŋ ɪn ə dʌzən dɝɛkʃənz waɪl ðə wʊlvz slu tʃɹɑləks, ɹʌnɪŋ əweɪ wɪð ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ. ɹʌnɪŋ əweɪ wɪð ðə dæɡɝ. ən wʌns ðə tʃɹɑləks wɝ dɛd, hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk i kəɾ ɪntʃɹəs ðə wʊlvz ɪn tʃɹækɪŋ ðə hjumənz ivən ɪf i hæɾ ɛni aɪdiə wɪtʃ ə ðɛm tə tʃɹæk. hi hæɾ ə ɹʌnɪŋ ɑɹɡjəmənt wɪð ðɛm, ən swɛt kʌvɝɾ ɪz fɔɹhɛd lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ i ɡɑt ðə fɝs flæʃ ʌv ɪmədʒəz ðət tɝn ɪz stʌmək.

Perrin took Hurin's place beside Ingtar as the small column rode south. Mat kept up a string of disparaging remarks, until Uno found the first tracks left by Trollocs and by men on horses, but Perrin paid him little mind. It was all he could do to keep the wolves from dashing on ahead to kill the Trollocs. The wolves cared only about killing the Twisted Ones; to them, Darkfriends were no different from any other two-legs. Perrin could almost see the Darkfriends scattering in a dozen directions while the wolves slew Trollocs, running away with the Horn of Valere. Running away with the dagger. And once the Trollocs were dead, he did not think he could interest the wolves in tracking the humans even if he had any idea which of them to track. He had a running argument with them, and sweat covered his forehead long before he got the first flash of images that turned his stomach.

hi dʒɹu ɹeɪn, stɑpɪŋ ɪz hɔɹs dɛd. ði ʌðɝz dɪd ðə seɪm, lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm, weɪɾɪŋ. hi stɛɹd stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛɾ ən kɝst sɔfli, bɪɾɝli.

He drew rein, stopping his horse dead. The others did the same, looking at him, waiting. He stared straight ahead and cursed softly, bitterly.

wʊlvz wəd kɪl mɛn, bʌt mɛn wɝ nɑɾ ə pɹəfɝd pɹeɪ. wʊlvz ɹɪmɛmbɝd ði oʊl hʌntɪŋ təɡɛðɝ, fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ, ən tu-lɛɡz teɪstəd bæd, fəɹ ənʌðɝ. wʊlvz wɝ mɔɹ pɝtɪkjəlɝ əbaʊt ðɛɹ fud ðən i wəɾ əv bɪlivd. ðeɪ wəd nɑɾ it kɛɹiən, ənlɛs ðeɪ wɝ stɑɹvɪŋ, ən fju wəd kɪl mɔɹ ðən ðeɪ kəɾ it. wʌt pɛɹɪn fɛl fɹəm ðə wʊlvz kəd bɛs bi dɪskɹaɪbd əz dɪsɡʌst. ən ðəɹ wɝ ði ɪmədʒəz. hi kəd si ðɛm mʌtʃ mɔɹ klɪɹli ðən i wɪʃt. bɑɾiz, mɛn ən wɪmən ən tʃɪlʒɹən, hipt ən tʌmbəld əbaʊt. blʌd-soʊkt ɝθ tʃɝn baɪ hʊvz ən fɹɛnziɾ ətɛmps tə ɪskeɪp. tɔɹn flɛʃ. hɛdz sɛvɝd. vʌltʃɝz flæpɪŋ, ðɛɹ waɪt wɪŋz steɪn ɹɛd; blʌɾi, fɛðɝləs hɛdz tɛɹɪŋ ən ɡɔɹdʒɪŋ. hi bɹoʊk lus bɪfɔɹ ɪz stʌmək ɛmptiɾ ɪtsɛlf.

Wolves would kill men, but men were not a preferred prey. Wolves remembered the old hunting together, for one thing, and two-legs tasted bad, for another. Wolves were more particular about their food than he would have believed. They would not eat carrion, unless they were starving, and few would kill more than they could eat. What Perrin felt from the wolves could best be described as disgust. And there were the images. He could see them much more clearly than he wished. Bodies, men and women and children, heaped and tumbled about. Blood-soaked earth churned by hooves and frenzied attempts to escape. Torn flesh. Heads severed. Vultures flapping, their white wings stained red; bloody, featherless heads tearing and gorging. He broke loose before his stomach emptied itself.

əbʌv səm tʃɹiz ɪn ðə fɑɹ dɪstəns i kəd dʒʌs meɪk aʊt blæk spɛks wɝlɪŋ loʊ, dʒɹɑpɪŋ ðən ɹaɪzɪŋ əɡɛn. vʌltʃɝz faɪɾɪŋ oʊvɝ ðɛɹ mil.

Above some trees in the far distance he could just make out black specks whirling low, dropping then rising again. Vultures fighting over their meal.

"ðɛɹz sʌmθɪŋ bæɾ ʌp ðɛɹ." hi swɑloʊd, miɾɪŋ ɪŋtʃɹz ɡeɪz. haʊ kəɾ i fɪt tɛlɪŋ əm ɪndə ðə stɔɹi ʌv biɪŋ ə snɪfɝ? aɪ doʊnt wɑnə ɡɛt kloʊs ɪnʌf tə lʊk ət ðæt. bʌt ðəl wɑnə ɪnvɛstəɡeɪt wʌns ðeɪ kən si ðə vʌltʃɝz. aɪ hæv tə tɛl əm ɪnʌf soʊ ðəl sɝkəl ɝaʊnd. "ðə pipəl fɹəm ðət vɪlədʒ. . . . aɪ θɪŋk ðə tʃɹɑləks kɪl ðɛm."

"There's something bad up there." He swallowed, meeting Ingtar's gaze. How could he fit telling them into the story of being a sniffer? I don't want to get close enough to look at that. But they'll want to investigate once they can see the vultures. I have to tell them enough so they'll circle around. "The people from that village. . . . I think the Trollocs killed them."

ənoʊ bɪɡæn kɝsɪŋ kwaɪətli, ən səm ə ði ʌðɝ ʃaɪnɝənz mʌɾɝd tə ðɛmsɛlvz. nʌn ə ðɛm sim tə teɪk ɪz ənaʊnsmən əz ɑd, ðoʊ. lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹ sɛɾ i wɑz ə snɪfɝ, ən snɪfɝz kəd smɛl kɪlɪŋ.

Uno began cursing quietly, and some of the other Shienarans muttered to themselves. None of them seemed to take his announcement as odd, though. Lord Ingtar said he was a sniffer, and sniffers could smell killing.

"æn ðəɹ ɪz sʌmwʌn fɑloʊɪŋ ʌs," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd.

"And there is someone following us," Ingtar said.

mæt tɝn ɪz hɔɹs iɡɝli. "meɪbi ɪts ɹænd. aɪ nu hi wʊdn ɹʌn aʊɾ ɑn mi."

Mat turned his horse eagerly. "Maybe it's Rand. I knew he wouldn't run out on me."

θɪn, skæɾɝd pʌfs ə dʌst ɹoʊz tə ðə nɔɹθ; ə hɔɹs wɑz ɹʌnɪŋ əkɹɔs pætʃəz wɛɹ ðə ɡɹæs ɡɹu θɪn. ðə ʃaɪnɝənz spɹɛɾ aʊt, lænsɪz ɹɛɾi, wɑtʃɪŋ ɪn ɔl dɝɛkʃənz. ɪt wɑz noʊ pleɪs tə bi kæʒəwəl əbaʊɾ ə stʃɹeɪnʒɝ.

Thin, scattered puffs of dust rose to the north; a horse was running across patches where the grass grew thin. The Shienarans spread out, lances ready, watching in all directions. It was no place to be casual about a stranger.

ə spɛk əpɪɹd - ə hɔɹs ən ɹaɪɾɝ; ə wʊmən, tə pɛɹɪnz aɪz, lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ɛniwʌn ɛls kəd dɪsɝn ðə ɹaɪɾɝ - ən kwɪkli dʒɹu kloʊsɝ. ʃi sloʊd tə ə tʃɹɑɾ əz ʃi keɪm ʌp ɑn ðɛm, fænɪŋ hɝsɛlf wɪð wʌn hænd. ə plʌmp, ɡɹeɪɪŋ wʊmən, wɪð əɹ kloʊk taɪd bɪhaɪn əɹ sæɾəl, hu blɪŋkt əɾ əm ɔl veɪɡli.

A speck appeared - a horse and rider; a woman, to Perrin's eyes, long before anyone else could discern the rider - and quickly drew closer. She slowed to a trot as she came up on them, fanning herself with one hand. A plump, graying woman, with her cloak tied behind her saddle, who blinked at them all vaguely.

"ðæts wʌn ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ," mæt sɛd dɪsəpɔɪntɪdli. "aɪ ɹɛkəɡnaɪz hɝ. vɛɹɪn."

"That's one of the Aes Sedai," Mat said disappointedly. "I recognize her. Verin."

"vɛɹɪn sədaɪ," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd ʃɑɹpli, ðən baʊd tə hɝ fɹəm ɪz sæɾəl.

"Verin Sedai," Ingtar said sharply, then bowed to her from his saddle.

"mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ sɛn mi, lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹ," vɛɹɪn ənaʊnst wɪð ə sæɾəsfaɪd smaɪl. "ʃi θɔt jə maɪt nid mi. sətʃ ə ɡæləp aɪv hæd. aɪ θɔɾ aɪ maɪt nɑt kætʃ jə ʃɔɹɾ ə kɛɹhin. jə sɔ ðət vɪlədʒ, ʌv kɔɹs? oʊ, ðət wɑz vɛɹi næsti, wɑzn ɪt? ən ðət mɹdʒɹɑl. ðəɹ wɝ ɹeɪvənz ən kɹoʊz ɔl oʊvɝ ðə ɹuftɑps, bʌt nɛvɝ ə wʌn wɛnt nɪɹ ɪt, dɛɾ əz ɪt wɑz. aɪ hæd tə weɪv əweɪ ðə dɑɹk wʌnz oʊn weɪɾ ɪn flaɪz, ðoʊ, bɪfɔɹ aɪ kəd meɪk aʊt wʌɾ ɪt wɑz. ə ʃeɪm aɪ dɪd nɑɾ əv taɪm tə teɪk ɪt daʊn. aɪv nɛvɝ hæɾ ə tʃæns tə stʌɾi ə - " sʌɾənli hɝ aɪz nɛɹoʊd, ən ði æbsən mænɝ vænɪʃt laɪk smoʊk. "wɛɹ ɪz ɹænd ælθɹ?"

"Moiraine Sedai sent me, Lord Ingtar," Verin announced with a satisfied smile. "She thought you might need me. Such a gallop I've had. I thought I might not catch you short of Cairhien. You saw that village, of course? Oh, that was very nasty, wasn't it? And that Myrddraal. There were ravens and crows all over the rooftops, but never a one went near it, dead as it was. I had to wave away the Dark One's own weight in flies, though, before I could make out what it was. A shame I did not have time to take it down. I've never had a chance to study a - " Suddenly her eyes narrowed, and the absent manner vanished like smoke. "Where is Rand al'Thor?"

ɪŋtʃɹ ɡɹɪməst. "ɡɔn, vɛɹɪn sədaɪ. vænɪʃt læs naɪt, wɪθaʊɾ ə tʃɹeɪs. hɪm, ði oʊɡiɝ, ən hʊɹɪn, wʌn ə maɪ mɛn."

Ingtar grimaced. "Gone, Verin Sedai. Vanished last night, without a trace. Him, the Ogier, and Hurin, one of my men."

"ði oʊɡiɝ, lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹ? ən jəɹ snɪfɝ wɛnt wɪð hɪm? wʌt wəd ðoʊz tu hæv ɪn kɑmən wɪð . . . ?" ɪŋtʃɹ ɡeɪpt ət hɝ, ən ʃi snɔɹɾɪd. "dɪd jə θɪŋk jə kəd kip sʌmθɪŋ laɪk ðət sikɹət?" ʃi snɔɹɾɪd əɡɛn. "snɪfɝz. vænɪʃt, jə seɪ?"

"The Ogier, Lord Ingtar? And your sniffer went with him? What would those two have in common with . . . ?" Ingtar gaped at her, and she snorted. "Did you think you could keep something like that secret?" She snorted again. "Sniffers. Vanished, you say?"

"jɛs, vɛɹɪn sədaɪ." ɪŋtʃɹ saʊndəɾ ənsɛɾəld. ɪt wɑz nɛvɝ izi dɪskʌvɝɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ nu ðə sikɹəts jə wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kip fɹəm ðɛm; pɛɹɪn hoʊp mɔɪɹeɪn hæd nɑt toʊld ɛniwʌn əbaʊt hɪm. "bʌɾ aɪ hæv - aɪ hæv ə nu snɪfɝ." ðə ʃaɪnɝən lɔɹd dʒɛstʃɝd tə pɛɹɪn. "ðɪs mæn simz tə hæv ði əbɪləɾi, ɔlsoʊ. əl faɪn ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ, əz aɪ swɔɹ tə, hæv noʊ fɪɹ. jəɹ kʌmpəni wɪl bi wɛlkəm, ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɪf jə wɪʃ tə ɹaɪd wɪð ʌs." tə pɛɹɪnz sɝpɹaɪz, hi dɪd nɑt saʊn əz ɪf i ɪntaɪɝli mɛn ɪt.

"Yes, Verin Sedai." Ingtar sounded unsettled. It was never easy discovering Aes Sedai knew the secrets you were trying to keep from them; Perrin hoped Moiraine had not told anyone about him. "But I have - I have a new sniffer." The Shienaran Lord gestured to Perrin. "This man seems to have the ability, also. I will find the Horn of Valere, as I swore to, have no fear. Your company will be welcome, Aes Sedai, if you wish to ride with us." To Perrin's surprise, he did not sound as if he entirely meant it.
