vɛɹɪn ɡlænst ət pɛɹɪn, ən i ʃɪftəɾ ənizəli. "ə nu snɪfɝ, dʒʌst wən jə luz jəɹ oʊld wʌn. haʊ . . . pɹɑvədɛntʃəl. jə faʊnd noʊ tʃɹæks? noʊ, ʌv kɔɹs nɑt. jə sɛd noʊ tʃɹeɪs. ɑd. læs naɪt." ʃi twɪstəɾ ɪn əɹ sæɾəl, lʊkɪŋ bæk nɔɹθ, ən fəɹ ə moʊmən pɛɹɪn ɔlmoʊs θɔt ʃi wɑz gɑnə ɹaɪd bæk ðə weɪ ʃi hæd kʌm.

Verin glanced at Perrin, and he shifted uneasily. "A new sniffer, just when you lose your old one. How . . . providential. You found no tracks? No, of course not. You said no trace. Odd. Last night." She twisted in her saddle, looking back north, and for a moment Perrin almost thought she was going to ride back the way she had come.

ɪŋtʃɹ fɹaʊn ət hɝ. "ju θɪŋk ðɛɹ dɪsəpɪɹəns əz sʌmθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðə hɔɹn, ɛɛs sədaɪ?"

Ingtar frowned at her. "You think their disappearance has something to do with the Horn, Aes Sedai?"

vɛɹɪn sɛɾəld bæk. "ðə hɔɹn? noʊ. noʊ, aɪ . . . θɪŋk nɑt. bʌɾ ɪts ɑd. vɛɹi ɑd. aɪ də nɑt laɪk ɑd θɪŋz əntɪl aɪ kən ʌndɝstæn ðɛm."

"aɪ kən əv tu mɛn ɛskɔɹt jə bæk tə wɛɹ ðeɪ dɪsəpɪɹd, vɛɹɪn sədaɪ. ðəl əv noʊ tʃɹʌbəl teɪkɪŋ jə ɹaɪt tə ɪt."

"No. If you say they vanished without a trace. . . ." For a long moment she studied Ingtar, her face unreadable. "I will ride with you. Perhaps we will find them again, or they will find us. Talk to me as we ride, Lord Ingtar. Tell me everything you can about the young man. Everything he did, everything he said."

ðeɪ stɑɹɾəd ɔf ɪn ə dʒɪŋɡəl ə hɑɹnəs ən ɑɹmɝ, vɛɹɪn ɹaɪɾɪŋ kloʊs bɪsaɪɾ ɪŋtʃɹ ən kwɛstʃənɪŋ ɪm kloʊsli, bʌt tu loʊ tə bi oʊvɝhɝd. ʃi ɡeɪv pɛɹɪn ə lʊk wən i tʃɹaɪd tə meɪnteɪn ɪz pleɪs, ən i fɛl bæk.

They started off in a jingle of harness and armor, Verin riding close beside Ingtar and questioning him closely, but too low to be overheard. She gave Perrin a look when he tried to maintain his place, and he fell back.

"ɪts ɹænd ʃiz æftɝ," mæt mɝmɝd, "nɑt ðə hɔɹn."

"It's Rand she's after," Mat murmured, "not the Horn."

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd. wɛɹɛvɝ juv ɡɑɾən tə, ɹænd, steɪ ðɛɹ. ɪts seɪfɝ ðən hɪɹ.

Perrin nodded. Wherever you've gotten to, Rand, stay there. It's safer than here.

Kinslayer

ðə weɪ ðə stʃɹeɪnʒli feɪɾəd dɪstən hɪlz sim tə slaɪd təwɔɹd ɹænd wən i lʊk stʃɹeɪɾ əɾ əm meɪɾ ɪz hɛd spɪn, ənlɛs i ɹæp hɪmsɛlf ɪn ðə vɔɪd. səmtaɪmz ði ɛmptinəs kɹɛpt ʌp ɑn ɪm ənəwɛɹz, bʌɾ i əvɔɪɾəd ɪt laɪk dɛθ. bɛɾɝ tə bi dɪzi ðən ʃɛɹ ðə vɔɪd wɪð ðəɾ ənizi laɪt. bɛɾɝ baɪ fɑɹ tə stɛɹ ət ðə feɪɾəd lænd. stɪl, hi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə lʊk əɾ ɛniθɪŋ tu fɑɹ əweɪ ənlɛs ɪt leɪ ɹaɪɾ əhɛɾ ə ðɛm.

The way the strangely faded distant hills seemed to slide toward Rand when he looked straight at them made his head spin, unless he wrapped himself in the void. Sometimes the emptiness crept up on him unawares, but he avoided it like death. Better to be dizzy than share the void with that uneasy light. Better by far to stare at the faded land. Still, he tried not to look at anything too far away unless it lay right ahead of them.

hʊɹɪn wɔɹ ə fɪks lʊk əz i kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾəd ɑn snɪfɪŋ ðə tʃɹeɪl, əz ɪf i wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɪɡnɔɹ ðə læn ðə tʃɹeɪl kɹɔst. wən ðə snɪfɝ dɪd noʊɾəs wʌt leɪ ɝaʊn ðɛm, hi wəd ɡɪv ə stɑɹɾ ən waɪp ɪz hænz ɑn ɪz koʊt, ðən pʊʃ ɪz noʊz fɔɹwɝd laɪk ə haʊnd, aɪz ɡleɪzɪŋ, ɪkskluɾɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls. lɔɪəl ɹoʊd slʌmpt ɪn ɪz sæɾəl ən fɹaʊn əz i ɡlænst ɝaʊnd, ɪɹz twɪtʃɪŋ ənizəli, mʌɾɝɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf.

Hurin wore a fixed look as he concentrated on sniffing the trail, as if he were trying to ignore the land the trail crossed. When the sniffer did notice what lay around them, he would give a start and wipe his hands on his coat, then push his nose forward like a hound, eyes glazing, excluding everything else. Loial rode slumped in his saddle and frowned as he glanced around, ears twitching uneasily, muttering to himself.

əɡɛn ðeɪ kɹɔs læn blækən ən bɝnd, ivən ðə sɔɪl kɹʌntʃɪŋ ʌndɝ ðə hɔɹsəz' hʊvz əz ɪf ɪt hæd bɪn sɪɹd. ðə bɝn swɑðz, səmtaɪmz ə maɪl waɪd, səmtaɪmz oʊnli ə fju hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz, ɔl ɹæn ist ən wɛst əz stʃɹeɪɾ əz ən æɹoʊz flaɪt. twaɪs ɹænd sɔ ði ɛn ʌv ə bɝn, wʌns əz ðeɪ ɹoʊɾ oʊvɝ ɪt, wʌns əz ðeɪ pæs nɪɹbaɪ; ðeɪ teɪpɝd tə pɔɪns ət ði ɛnz. ət list, ði ɛnz i sɔ wɝ soʊ, bʌɾ i səspɛktəd ðeɪ wɝ ɔl ðə seɪm.

Again they crossed land blackened and burned, even the soil crunching under the horses' hooves as if it had been seared. The burned swathes, sometimes a mile wide, sometimes only a few hundred paces, all ran east and west as straight as an arrow's flight. Twice Rand saw the end of a burn, once as they rode over it, once as they passed nearby; they tapered to points at the ends. At least, the ends he saw were so, but he suspected they were all the same.

wʌns i hæd wɑtʃt wʌtli ɛldɪn dɛkɝeɪɾ ə kɑɹt fəɹ sʌndeɪ, bæk hoʊm ɪn ɛmənz fild, wʌt peɪntɪŋ ðə sinz ɪn bɹaɪt kʌlɝz, ən ði ɪntʃɹəkət skɹɑlwɝk ðət sɝaʊndəd ðɛm. fəɹ ðə bɔɹɾɝz, wʌt lɛt ðə pɔɪn ə hɪz bɹʌʃ tʌtʃ ðə kɑɹt, meɪkɪŋ ə θɪn laɪn ðət ɡɹu θɪkɝ əz i pɹɛs hɑɹɾɝ, ðən θɪnɝ əɡɛn əz i izd ʌp. ðət wɑz haʊ ðə læn lʊkt, əz ɪf sʌmwʌn hæd stʃɹikt ɪt wɪð ə mɑnstʃɹəs bɹʌʃ ə faɪɝ.

Once he had watched Whatley Eldin decorate a cart for Sunday, back home in Emond's Field, What painting the scenes in bright colors, and the intricate scrollwork that surrounded them. For the borders, What let the point of his brush touch the cart, making a thin line that grew thicker as he pressed harder, then thinner again as he eased up. That was how the land looked, as if someone had streaked it with a monstrous brush of fire.

nʌθɪŋ ɡɹu wɛɹ ðə bɝnz wɝ, ðoʊ səm bɝnz, ət list, hæd ðə fil ʌv ə θɪŋ lɔŋ dʌn. nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə hɪn ə tʃɑɹ ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ði ɛɹ ðɛɹ, nɑɾ ə wɪf ivən wən i lin daʊn tə bɹeɪk ɔf ə blæk twɪɡ ən smɛl ɪt. oʊld, jɛt nʌθɪŋ hæd kʌm ɪn tə ɹikleɪm ðə lænd. blæk ɡeɪv weɪ tə ɡɹin, ən ɡɹin tə blæk, əlɔŋ naɪf-ɛdʒ laɪnz.

Nothing grew where the burns were, though some burns, at least, had the feel of a thing long done. Not so much as a hint of char remained in the air there, not a whiff even when he leaned down to break off a black twig and smell it. Old, yet nothing had come in to reclaim the land. Black gave way to green, and green to black, along knife-edge lines.

ɪn ɪts oʊn weɪ, ðə ɹɛst ə ðə læn leɪ əz dɛɾ əz ðə bɝnz, ðoʊ ɡɹæs kʌvɝd ðə ɡɹaʊn ən livz kʌvɝd ðə tʃɹiz. ɛvɹiθɪŋ hæd ðət feɪɾəd lʊk, laɪk kloʊðz tu ɔfən wɑʃt ən tu lɔŋ lɛft ɪn ðə sʌn. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ bɝdz əɹ ænəməlz, nɑt ðət ɹænd sɔ əɹ hɝd. noʊ hɔk wilɪŋ ɪn ðə skaɪ, noʊ bɑɹk ʌv ə hʌntɪŋ fɑks, noʊ bɝd sɪŋɪŋ. nʌθɪŋ ɹʌsəld ɪn ðə ɡɹæs əɹ lɪɾ ɑn ə tʃɹi bɹæntʃ. noʊ biz, əɹ bʌɾɝflaɪz. sɛvɹəl taɪmz ðeɪ kɹɔst stʃɹimz, ðə wɔɾɝ ʃæloʊ, ðoʊ ɔfən ɪt hæd dʌɡ ɪtsɛlf ə dip ɡʌli wɪð stip bæŋks ðə hɔɹsəz hæd tə skɹæmbəl daʊn ən klaɪm ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd. ðə wɔɾɝ ɹæn klɪɹ ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə mʌd ðə hɔɹsəz' hʊvz stɝd, bʌt nɛvɝ ə mɪnoʊ əɹ tædpoʊl ɹɪəld aʊɾ ə ðə ɹɔɪlɪŋ, nɑɾ ivən ə wɔɾɝspədɝ dænsɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə sɝfəs, əɹ ə hʌvɝɪŋ leɪsɪŋ.

In its own way, the rest of the land lay as dead as the burns, though grass covered the ground and leaves covered the trees. Everything had that faded look, like clothes too often washed and too long left in the sun. There were no birds or animals, not that Rand saw or heard. No hawk wheeling in the sky, no bark of a hunting fox, no bird singing. Nothing rustled in the grass or lit on a tree branch. No bees, or butterflies. Several times they crossed streams, the water shallow, though often it had dug itself a deep gulley with steep banks the horses had to scramble down and climb on the other side. The water ran clear except for the mud the horses' hooves stirred, but never a minnow or tadpole wriggled out of the roiling, not even a waterspider dancing across the surface, or a hovering lacewing.

ðə wɔɾɝ wɑz dʒɹɪŋkəbəl, wɪtʃ wɑz dʒʌst əz wɛl, sɪns ðɛɹ wɔɾɝbətəlz kəd nɑt læs fɝɛvɝ. ɹænd teɪstəɾ ɪt fɝst, ən meɪd lɔɪəl ən hʊɹɪn weɪt tə si ɪf ɛniθɪŋ hæpən tə hɪm bɪfɔɹ i lɛɾ əm dʒɹɪŋk. hi hæd ɡɑɾən əm ɪndə ðɪs; ɪt wɑz ɪz ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi. ðə wɔɾɝ wɑz kul ən wɛt, bʌt ðət wɑz ðə bɛs ðət kəd bi sɛd fəɹ ɪt. ɪt teɪstəd flæt, əz ɪf ɪt hæd bɪn bɔɪld. lɔɪəl meɪɾ ə feɪs, ən ðə hɔɹsəz dɪd nɑt laɪk ɪɾ iðɝ, ʃeɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ hɛdz ən dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ ɹɪlʌktənli.

The water was drinkable, which was just as well, since their waterbottles could not last forever. Rand tasted it first, and made Loial and Hurin wait to see if anything happened to him before he let them drink. He had gotten them into this; it was his responsibility. The water was cool and wet, but that was the best that could be said for it. It tasted flat, as if it had been boiled. Loial made a face, and the horses did not like it either, shaking their heads and drinking reluctantly.

ðəɹ wɑz wʌn saɪn ə laɪf; ət list, ɹænd θɔɾ ɪt mʌs bi soʊ. twaɪs i sɔ ə wɪspi stʃɹik kɹɔlɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə skaɪ laɪk ə laɪn dʒɹɔn wɪð klaʊd. ðə laɪnz wɝ tu stʃɹeɪt tə bi nætʃɹəl, ɪt simd, bʌɾ i kəd nɑɾ ɪmædʒən wʌt maɪt meɪk ðɛm. hi dɪd nɑt mɛnʃən ðə laɪnz tə ði ʌðɝz. pɝhæps ðeɪ dɪd nɑt si, hʊɹɪn ɪntɛn ɑn ðə tʃɹeɪl əz i wɑz ən lɔɪəl dʒɹɔn ɪn ɑn hɪmsɛlf. ðeɪ sɛd nʌθɪŋ ə ðə laɪnz, əɾ ɛni ɹeɪt.

There was one sign of life; at least, Rand thought it must be so. Twice he saw a wispy streak crawling across the sky like a line drawn with cloud. The lines were too straight to be natural, it seemed, but he could not imagine what might make them. He did not mention the lines to the others. Perhaps they did not see, Hurin intent on the trail as he was and Loial drawn in on himself. They said nothing of the lines, at any rate.

wən ðeɪ hæd ɹɪɾən hæf ðə mɔɹnɪŋ, lɔɪəl əbɹʌpli swʌŋ daʊn fɹəm ɪz hjudʒ hɔɹs wɪθaʊɾ ə wɝɾ ən stʃɹoʊd tə ə stæn ə dʒɑnsbɹum, ðɛɹ tʃɹʌŋks splɪɾɪŋ ɪndə mɛni θɪk bɹæntʃəz, stɪf ən stʃɹeɪt, nɑɾ ə peɪs əbʌv ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ət ðə tɑp, ɔl splɪɾ əɡɛn, ɪndə ðə lifi bɹʌʃ ðət ɡeɪv əm ðɛɹ neɪm.

When they had ridden half the morning, Loial abruptly swung down from his huge horse without a word and strode to a stand of giantsbroom, their trunks splitting into many thick branches, stiff and straight, not a pace above the ground. At the top, all split again, into the leafy brush that gave them their name.

ɹænd pʊld ɹɛɾ ʌp ən stɑɹɾəd tə æsk wʌɾ i wɑz duɪŋ, bʌt sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ði oʊɡiɝz mænɝ, əz ɪf i hɪmsɛlf wɝ ənsɝɾən, kɛpt ɹænd saɪlənt. æftɝ stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə tʃɹi, lɔɪəl pʊɾ ɪz hænz ɑn ə tʃɹʌŋk ən bɪɡæn tə sɪŋ ɪn ə dip, sɑft ɹʌmbəl.

Rand pulled Red up and started to ask what he was doing, but something about the Ogier's manner, as if he himself were uncertain, kept Rand silent. After staring at the tree, Loial put his hands on a trunk and began to sing in a deep, soft rumble.

ɹænd hæd hɝɾ oʊɡiɝ tʃɹisɔŋ, wʌns, wən lɔɪəl hæd sʌŋ tə ə daɪɪŋ tʃɹi ən bɹɔɾ ɪt bæk tə laɪf, ən i hæd hɝɾ ə sʌŋ wʊd, ɑbʒɛkts ɹɔt fɹəm tʃɹiz baɪ ðə tʃɹisɔŋ. ðə tælənt wɑz feɪɾɪŋ, lɔɪəl sɛd, hi wɑz wʌn ə ðə fju hu hæd ði əbɪləɾi, naʊ; ðət wɑz wʌt meɪd sʌŋ wʊɾ ivən mɔɹ sɔɾ æftɝ ən tʃɹɛʒɝd. wən i hæd hɝd lɔɪəl sɪŋ bɪfɔɹ, ɪt hæd bɪn əz ɪf ði ɝθ ɪtsɛlf sæŋ, bʌt naʊ ði oʊɡiɝ mɝmɝɾ ɪz sɔŋ ɔlmoʊs dɪfəɾəntli, ən ðə læn ɛkoʊɾ ɪɾ ɪn ə wɪspɝ.

Rand had heard Ogier Treesong, once, when Loial had sung to a dying tree and brought it back to life, and he had heard of sung wood, objects wrought from trees by the Treesong. The Talent was fading, Loial said, he was one of the few who had the ability, now; that was what made sung wood even more sought after and treasured. When he had heard Loial sing before, it had been as if the earth itself sang, but now the Ogier murmured his song almost diffidently, and the land echoed it in a whisper.

ɪt sim pjʊɹ sɔŋ, mjuzɪk wɪθaʊt wɝdz, ət lis nʌn ðət ɹænd kəd meɪk aʊt; ɪf ðəɹ wɝ wɝdz, ðeɪ feɪɾəd ɪndə ðə mjuzɪk dʒʌst əz wɔɾɝ pɔɹz ɪndə ə stʃɹim. hʊɹɪn ɡæspt ən stɛɹd.

It seemed pure song, music without words, at least none that Rand could make out; if there were words, they faded into the music just as water pours into a stream. Hurin gasped and stared.

ɹænd wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ wʌɾ ɪt wɑz lɔɪəl dɪd, əɹ haʊ; sɑft əz ðə sɔŋ wɑz, ɪt kɑɾ ɪm ʌp hɪpnɑɾəkəli, fɪlɪŋ ɪz maɪn ɔlmoʊs ðə weɪ ðə vɔɪd dɪd. lɔɪəl ɹæn ɪz bɪɡ hænz əlɔŋ ðə tʃɹʌŋk, sɪŋɪŋ, kɝɛsɪŋ wɪð ɪz vɔɪs əz wɛl əz ɪz fɪŋɡɝz. ðə tʃɹʌŋk naʊ sim smuðɝ, sʌmhaʊ, əz ɪf ɪz stʃɹoʊkɪŋ wɝ ʃeɪpɪŋ ɪt. ɹænd blɪŋkt. hi wɑz ʃʊɹ ðə pis lɔɪəl wɝkt ɑn hæd hæd bɹæntʃəz əɾ ɪts tɑp dʒʌs laɪk ði ʌðɝz, bʌt naʊ ɪt stɑpt ɪn ə ɹaʊndəɾ ɛn ɹaɪɾ əbʌv ði oʊɡiɝz hɛd. ɹænd oʊpən ɪz maʊθ, bʌt ðə sɔŋ kwaɪəɾəd hɪm. ɪt sim soʊ fəmɪljɝ, ðət sɔŋ, əz ɪf i ʃəd noʊ ɪt.

Rand was not sure what it was Loial did, or how; soft as the song was, it caught him up hypnotically, filling his mind almost the way the void did. Loial ran his big hands along the trunk, singing, caressing with his voice as well as his fingers. The trunk now seemed smoother, somehow, as if his stroking were shaping it. Rand blinked. He was sure the piece Loial worked on had had branches at its top just like the others, but now it stopped in a rounded end right above the Ogier's head. Rand opened his mouth, but the song quieted him. It seemed so familiar, that song, as if he should know it.

əbɹʌpli lɔɪəlz vɔɪs ɹoʊz tə ə klaɪmæks - ɔlmoʊst ə hɪm ə θæŋks, ɪt saʊndəd - ən ɛndəd, feɪɾɪŋ əz ə bɹiz feɪdz.

Abruptly Loial's voice rose to a climax - almost a hymn of thanks, it sounded - and ended, fading as a breeze fades.

"bɝn mi," hʊɹɪn bɹiðd. hi lʊk stʌnd. "bɝn mi, aɪ nɛvɝ hɝɾ ɛniθɪŋ laɪk. . . . bɝn mi."

"Burn me," Hurin breathed. He looked stunned. "Burn me, I never heard anything like. . . . Burn me."

ɪn ɪz hænz lɔɪəl hɛld ə stæf əz tɔl əz i wɑz ən əz θɪk əz ɹændz fɔɹɑɹm, smuð ən pɑlɪʃt. wɛɹ ðə tʃɹʌŋk hæd bɪn ɑn ðə dʒɑnsbɹum wɑz ə smɔl stɛm ə nu ɡɹoʊθ.

In his hands Loial held a staff as tall as he was and as thick as Rand's forearm, smooth and polished. Where the trunk had been on the giantsbroom was a small stem of new growth.

ɹænd tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. ɔlweɪz sʌmθɪŋ nu, ɔlweɪz sʌmθɪŋ aɪ dɪdn ɪkspɛkt, ən səmtaɪmz ɪɾ ɪzən hɔɹəbəl.

Rand took a deep breath. Always something new, always something I didn't expect, and sometimes it isn't horrible.

hi wɑtʃt lɔɪəl maʊnt, ɹɛstɪŋ ðə stæf əkɹɔs ɪz sæɾəl ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm, ən wʌndɝd waɪ ði oʊɡiɝ wɑntəɾ ə stæf əɾ ɔl, sɪns ðeɪ wɝ ɹaɪɾɪŋ. ðən i sɔ ðə θɪk ɹɑd, nɑɾ əz bɪɡ əz ɪt wɑz, bʌɾ ɪn ɹileɪʃən tə ði oʊɡiɝ, sɔ ðə weɪ lɔɪəl hændəld ɪt. "ə kɔɹɾɝstæf," hi sɛd, sɝpɹaɪzd. "aɪ dɪdnt noʊ oʊɡiɝ kæɹid wɛpənz, lɔɪəl."

He watched Loial mount, resting the staff across his saddle in front of him, and wondered why the Ogier wanted a staff at all, since they were riding. Then he saw the thick rod, not as big as it was, but in relation to the Ogier, saw the way Loial handled it. "A quarterstaff," he said, surprised. "I didn't know Ogier carried weapons, Loial."

"juʒəwəli wi də nɑt," ði oʊɡiɝ ɹɪplaɪɾ ɔlmoʊs kɝtli. "juʒəwəli. ðə pɹaɪs əz ɔlweɪz bɪn tu haɪ." hi hɛftəd ðə hjudʒ kɔɹɾɝstæf ən ɹɪŋkəld ɪz bɹɔd noʊz wɪð dɪsteɪst. "ɛldɝ heɪmən wəd ʃʊɹli seɪ aɪm pʊɾɪŋ ə lɔŋ hændəl ɑn maɪ æks, bʌɾ aɪm nɑt dʒʌs biɪŋ heɪsti əɹ ɹæʃ, ɹænd. ðɪs pleɪs. . . ." hi ʃɪvɝd, ən ɪz ɪɹz twɪtʃt.

"Usually we do not," the Ogier replied almost curtly. "Usually. The price has always been too high." He hefted the huge quarterstaff and wrinkled his broad nose with distaste. "Elder Haman would surely say I am putting a long handle on my axe, but I am not just being hasty or rash, Rand. This place. . . ." He shivered, and his ears twitched.

"wil faɪn əɹ weɪ bæk sun," ɹænd sɛd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə saʊn kɑnfəɾənt.

"We'll find our way back soon," Rand said, trying to sound confident.

lɔɪəl spoʊk əz ɪf i hæd nɑt hɝd. "ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪz . . . lɪŋkt, ɹænd. wɛðɝ ɪt laɪvz əɹ nɑt, wɛðɝ ɪt θɪŋks əɹ nɑt, ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðəɾ ɪz, fɪts təɡɛðɝ. ðə tʃɹi dʌz nɑt θɪŋk, bʌɾ ɪts pɑɹɾ ə ðə hoʊl, ən ðə hoʊl əz ə - ə filɪŋ. aɪ kæn ɪkspleɪn ɛni mɔɹ ðən aɪ kən ɪkspleɪn wʌt biɪŋ hæpi ɪz, bʌt. . . . ɹænd, ðɪs lænd wɑz ɡlæd fəɹ ə wɛpən tə bi meɪd. ɡlæd!"

Loial spoke as if he had not heard. "Everything is . . . linked, Rand. Whether it lives or not, whether it thinks or not, everything that is, fits together. The tree does not think, but it is part of the whole, and the whole has a - a feeling. I can't explain any more than I can explain what being happy is, but. . . . Rand, this land was glad for a weapon to be made. Glad!"

"ðə laɪt ʃaɪn ɑn ʌs," hʊɹɪn mɝmɝd nɝvəsli, "æn ðə kɹieɪɾɝz hænd ʃɛltɝ ʌs. ðoʊ wi ɡoʊ tə ðə læst ɛmbɹeɪs ə ðə mʌðɝ, ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin əɹ weɪ." hi kɛpt ɹɪpiɾɪŋ ðə kæɾəkɪzəm əz ɪf ɪt hæɾ ə tʃɑɹm tə pɹətɛk hɪm.

"The Light shine on us," Hurin murmured nervously, "and the Creator's hand shelter us. Though we go to the last embrace of the mother, the Light illumine our way." He kept repeating the catechism as if it had a charm to protect him.

ɹænd ɹɪzɪstɪd ði ɪmpəls tə lʊk ɝaʊnd. hi dɛfənətli dɪd nɑt lʊk ʌp. ɔl ɪt wəd teɪk tə bɹeɪk əm ɔl wɑz ənʌðɝ ə ðoʊz smoʊki laɪnz əkɹɔs ðə skaɪ ɹaɪɾ ət ðət moʊmənt. "ðɛɹz nʌθɪŋ hɪɹ tə hɝɾ ʌs," hi sɛd fɝmli. "ænd wɪl kip ə ɡʊd wɑtʃ ən meɪk ʃʊɹ nʌθɪŋ dʌz."

Rand resisted the impulse to look around. He definitely did not look up. All it would take to break them all was another of those smoky lines across the sky right at that moment. "There's nothing here to hurt us," he said firmly. "And we'll keep a good watch and make sure nothing does."

hi wɑntəd tə læf ət hɪmsɛlf, saʊndɪŋ soʊ sɝɾən. hi wɑz nɑt sɝɾən əbaʊɾ ɛniθɪŋ. bʌt wɑtʃɪŋ ði ʌðɝz - lɔɪəl wɪð ɪz tʌftəɾ ɪɹz dʒɹupɪŋ, ən hʊɹɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑt tə lʊk əɾ ɛniθɪŋ - hi nu wʌn ə ðɛm hæd tə sim tə bi ʃʊɹ, ət list, əɹ fɪɹ ən ənsɝɾənti wəd bɹeɪk əm ɔl əpɑɹt. ðə wil wivz əz ðə wil wɪlz. hi skwiz ðət θɔɾ aʊt. nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðə wil. nʌθɪŋ tə wɪð tɑvɝən, əɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ, əɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən. ɪts dʒʌs ðə weɪ ɪɾ ɪz, ðæts ɔl.

He wanted to laugh at himself, sounding so certain. He was not certain about anything. But watching the others - Loial with his tufted ears drooping, and Hurin trying not to look at anything - he knew one of them had to seem to be sure, at least, or fear and uncertainty would break them all apart. The Wheel weaves as the Wheel wills. He squeezed that thought out. Nothing to do with the Wheel. Nothing to with ta'veren, or Aes Sedai, or the Dragon. It's just the way it is, that's all.

"lɔɪəl, ɑɹ jə dʌn hɪɹ?" ði oʊɡiɝ nɑɾəd, ɹɪɡɹɛtfəli ɹʌbɪŋ ðə kɔɹɾɝstæf. ɹænd tɝn tə hʊɹɪn. "du jə stɪl əv ðə tʃɹeɪl?"

"Loial, are you done here?" The Ogier nodded, regretfully rubbing the quarterstaff. Rand turned to Hurin. "Do you still have the trail?"

"aɪ du, lɔɹd ɹænd. aɪ də ðæt."

"I do, Lord Rand. I do that."

"ðɛn lɛts kip ɑn wɪð ɪt. wʌns wi faɪn feɪn ən ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz, waɪ, wɪl ɡoʊ hoʊm hɪɹoʊz, wɪð ðə dæɡɝ fəɹ mæt, ən ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ. lɛɾ aʊt, hʊɹɪn." hɪɹoʊz? əl sɛɾəl fəɹ ɔl ʌv əs ɡɛɾɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɪɹ əlaɪv.

"Then let's keep on with it. Once we find Fain and the Darkfriends, why, we'll go home heroes, with the dagger for Mat, and the Horn of Valere. Lead out, Hurin." Heroes? I'll settle for all of us getting out of here alive.

"aɪ də nɑt laɪk ðɪs pleɪs," ði oʊɡiɝ ənaʊns flætli. hi hɛl ðə kɔɹɾɝstæf əz ɪf i ɪkspɛktəd tə hæv tə juz ɪt sun.

"I do not like this place," the Ogier announced flatly. He held the quarterstaff as if he expected to have to use it soon.

"æz wɛl wi doʊn min tə steɪ hɪɹ, ðɛn, ɪzən ɪt?" ɹænd sɛd. hʊɹɪn bɑɹkt ə læf əz ɪf i hæd meɪɾ ə dʒoʊk, bʌt lɔɪəl ɡeɪv ɪm ə lɛvəl lʊk.

"As well we don't mean to stay here, then, isn't it?" Rand said. Hurin barked a laugh as if he had made a joke, but Loial gave him a level look.

"æz wɛl wi doʊnt, ɹænd."

"As well we don't, Rand."

jɛɾ əz ðeɪ ɹoʊɾ ɑn saʊθwɝd, hi kəd si ðəɾ ɪz kæʒəwəl əsʌmpʃən ðət ðeɪ wəd ɡɛt hoʊm hæd pɪkt əm boʊθ ʌp ə lɪɾəl. hʊɹɪn sæɾ ə bɪt stʃɹeɪɾɝ ɪn ɪz sæɾəl, ən lɔɪəlz ɪɹz dɪd nɑt sim soʊ wɪltɪd. ɪt wɑz noʊ taɪm əɹ pleɪs tə lɛɾ əm noʊ hi ʃɛɹd ðɛɹ fɪɹ, soʊ hi kɛpt ɪt tə hɪmsɛlf, ən fɔɾ ɪt baɪ hɪmsɛlf.

Yet as they rode on southward, he could see that his casual assumption that they would get home had picked them both up a little. Hurin sat a bit straighter in his saddle, and Loial's ears did not seem so wilted. It was no time or place to let them know he shared their fear, so he kept it to himself, and fought it by himself.

hʊɹɪn kɛpt ɪz hjumɝ θɹu ðə mɔɹnɪŋ, mɝmɝɪŋ, "æz wɛl wi doʊn min tə steɪ," ðən tʃʌklɪŋ, əntɪl ɹænd fɛlt laɪk tɛlɪŋ ɪm tə bi kwaɪət. təwɔɹd mɪddeɪ, ðə snɪfɝ dɪd fɔl saɪlənt, ðoʊ, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ ən fɹaʊnɪŋ, ən ɹænd faʊn i wɪʃt ðə mæn wɑz stɪl ɹɪpiɾɪŋ ɪz wɝdz ən læfɪŋ.

Hurin kept his humor through the morning, murmuring, "As well we don't mean to stay," then chuckling, until Rand felt like telling him to be quiet. Toward midday, the sniffer did fall silent, though, shaking his head and frowning, and Rand found he wished the man was still repeating his words and laughing.

"ɪz ðəɹ sʌmθɪŋ ɹɔŋ wɪð ðə tʃɹeɪl, hʊɹɪn?" hi æskt.

"Is there something wrong with the trail, Hurin?" he asked.

ðə snɪfɝ ʃɹʌɡd, lʊkɪŋ tʃɹʌbəld. "jɛs, lɔɹd ɹænd, ən ðən əɡɛn noʊ, əz jə maɪt seɪ."

The sniffer shrugged, looking troubled. "Yes, Lord Rand, and then again no, as you might say."

"ɪt mʌs bi wʌn əɹ ði ʌðɝ. hæv jə lɔs ðə tʃɹeɪl? noʊ ʃeɪm ɪf jə hæv. jə sɛɾ ɪt wɑz wik tə stɑɹt. ɪf wi kæn faɪn ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz, wɪl faɪn ənʌðɝ stoʊn ən ɡɛt bæk ðət weɪ." laɪt, ɛniθɪŋ bʌt ðæt. ɹænd kɛpt ɪz feɪs smuð. "ɪf dɑɹkfɹɛnz kən kʌm hɪɹ ən liv, soʊ kən wi."

"It must be one or the other. Have you lost the trail? No shame if you have. You said it was weak to start. If we can't find the Darkfriends, we will find another Stone and get back that way." Light, anything but that. Rand kept his face smooth. "If Darkfriends can come here and leave, so can we."

"oʊ, aɪ hævən lɔst ɪt, lɔɹd ɹænd. aɪ kən stɪl pɪk aʊt ðə stɪŋk ə ðɛm. ɪɾ ɪzən ðæt. ɪts dʒʌst. . . . ɪts. . . ." wɪð ə ɡɹɪmɑs, hʊɹɪn bɝst aʊt, "ɪts laɪk aɪm ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ɪt, lɔɹd ɹænd, ɪnstɛɾ ə smɛlɪŋ ɪt. bʌɾ aɪm nɑt. ðɛɹz dʌzənz ə tʃɹeɪlz kɹɔsɪŋ ɪɾ ɔl ðə taɪm, dʌzənz ən dʌzənz, ən ɔl sɔɹts ə smɛlz ə vaɪələns, səm ə ðɛm fɹɛʃ, ɔlmoʊst, oʊnli wɑʃt aʊt laɪk ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls. ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ, ɹaɪɾ æftɝ wi lɛf ðə hɑloʊ, aɪ cʊɾə swɔɹn ðəɹ wɝ hʌnʒɹədz slɔɾɝd ɹaɪɾ ʌndɝ maɪ fit, dʒʌs mɪnəts bɪfɔɹ, bʌt ðəɹ wɝn ɛni bɑɾiz, ən nɑɾ ə mɑɹk ɑn ðə ɡɹæs bʌɾ əɹ oʊn hʊfpɹɪns. ə θɪŋ laɪk ðət kʊdn hæpən wɪθaʊt ðə ɡɹaʊn biɪŋ tɔɹn ʌp ən blʌɾid, bʌt ðəɹ wɑzn ə mɑɹk. ɪts ɔl laɪk ðæt, maɪ lɔɹd. bʌɾ aɪm fɑloʊɪŋ ðə tʃɹeɪl. aɪ æm. ðɪs pleɪs dʒʌst əz mi ɔl ɑn ɛdʒ. ðæts ɪt. ðət mʌs bi ɪt."

"Oh, I haven't lost it, Lord Rand. I can still pick out the stink of them. It isn't that. It's just. . . . It's. . . ." With a grimace, Hurin burst out, "It's like I'm remembering it, Lord Rand, instead of smelling it. But I'm not. There's dozens of trails crossing it all the time, dozens and dozens, and all sorts of smells of violence, some of them fresh, almost, only washed out like everything else. This morning, right after we left the hollow, I could have sworn there were hundreds slaughtered right under my feet, just minutes before, but there weren't any bodies, and not a mark on the grass but our own hoofprints. A thing like that couldn't happen without the ground being torn up and bloodied, but there wasn't a mark. It's all like that, my Lord. But I am following the trail. I am. This place just has me all on edge. That's it. That must be it."

ɹænd ɡlænst ət lɔɪəl - ði oʊɡiɝ dɪd kʌm ʌp wɪð ði ɑɾəst nɑlədʒ, ət taɪmz - bʌɾ i lʊkt əz pʌzəld əz hʊɹɪn. ɹænd meɪɾ ɪz vɔɪs mɔɹ kɑnfəɾənt ðən i fɛlt. "aɪ noʊ jə ɑɹ duɪŋ jəɹ bɛst, hʊɹɪn. wəɹ ɔl ʌv əs ɑn ɛdʒ. dʒʌs fɑloʊ əz bɛs jə kæn, ən wɪl faɪn ðɛm."

Rand glanced at Loial - the Ogier did come up with the oddest knowledge, at times - but he looked as puzzled as Hurin. Rand made his voice more confident than he felt. "I know you are doing your best, Hurin. We are all of us on edge. Just follow as best you can, and we'll find them."

"æz jə seɪ, lɔɹd ɹænd." hʊɹɪn buɾɪd ɪz hɔɹs fɔɹwɝd. "æz jə seɪ."

"As you say, Lord Rand." Hurin booted his horse forward. "As you say."

bʌt baɪ naɪtfɔl, ðəɹ wɑz stɪl noʊ saɪn ə ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz, ən hʊɹɪn sɛd ðə tʃɹeɪl wɑz feɪntɝ stɪl. ðə snɪfɝ kɛp mʌɾɝɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf əbaʊt "ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ."

But by nightfall, there was still no sign of the Darkfriends, and Hurin said the trail was fainter still. The sniffer kept muttering to himself about "remembering."

ðəɹ hæd bɪn noʊ saɪn. ɹɪli noʊ saɪn. ɹænd wɑz nɑɾ əz ɡʊɾ ə tʃɹækɝ əz ənoʊ, bʌɾ ɛni bɔɪ ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz wɑz ɪkspɛktəd tə tʃɹæk wɛl ɪnʌf tə faɪn ə lɔst ʃip, əɹ ə ɹæbət fəɹ dɪnɝ. hi hæd sin nʌθɪŋ. ɪt wɑz əz ɪf noʊ lɪvɪŋ θɪŋ hæɾ ɛvɝ dɪstɝb ðə læn bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ keɪm. ðəɹ ʃʊɾə bɪn sʌmθɪŋ ɪf ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz wɝ əhɛɾ ə ðɛm. bʌt hʊɹɪn kɛp fɑloʊɪŋ ðə tʃɹeɪl i sɛɾ i smɛld.

There had been no sign. Really no sign. Rand was not as good a tracker as Uno, but any boy in the Two Rivers was expected to track well enough to find a lost sheep, or a rabbit for dinner. He had seen nothing. It was as if no living thing had ever disturbed the land before they came. There should have been something if the Darkfriends were ahead of them. But Hurin kept following the trail he said he smelled.

əz ðə sʌn tʌtʃt ðə hɝaɪzən ðeɪ meɪd kæmp ɪn ə stæn ə tʃɹiz əntʌtʃt baɪ ðə bɝn, iɾɪŋ fɹəm ðɛɹ sæɾəlbæɡz. flætbɹɛɾ ən dʒɹaɪd mit wɑʃt daʊn wɪð flæt-teɪstɪŋ wɔɾɝ; hɑɹdli ə fɪlɪŋ mil, tʌf ən fɑɹ fɹəm teɪsti. ɹænd θɔt ðeɪ maɪɾ əv ɪnʌf fəɹ ə wik. æftɝ ðæt. . . . hʊɹɪn eɪt sloʊli, dətɝmənədli, bʌt lɔɪəl ɡʌlpt ɪz daʊn wɪð ə ɡɹɪmɑs ən sɛɾəld bæk wɪð ɪz paɪp, ðə bɪɡ kɔɹɾɝstæf kloʊs ət hænd. ɹænd kɛp ðɛɹ faɪɝ smɔl ən wɛl hɪɾən ɪn ðə tʃɹiz. feɪn ən ɪz dɑɹkfɹɛnz ən tʃɹɑləks maɪt bi kloʊs ɪnʌf tə si ə faɪɝ, fəɹ ɔl ə hʊɹɪnz wɝiz əbaʊt ði ɑdnəs ə ðɛɹ tʃɹeɪl.

As the sun touched the horizon they made camp in a stand of trees untouched by the burn, eating from their saddlebags. Flatbread and dried meat washed down with flat-tasting water; hardly a filling meal, tough and far from tasty. Rand thought they might have enough for a week. After that. . . . Hurin ate slowly, determinedly, but Loial gulped his down with a grimace and settled back with his pipe, the big quarterstaff close at hand. Rand kept their fire small and well hidden in the trees. Fain and his Darkfriends and Trollocs might be close enough to see a fire, for all of Hurin's worries about the oddness of their trail.

ɪt simd ɑd tə hɪm ðəɾ i hæd bɪɡʌn tə θɪŋk ə ðɛm əz feɪnz dɑɹkfɹɛnz, feɪnz tʃɹɑləks. feɪn wɑz dʒʌst ə mædmæn. ðən waɪ dɪd ðeɪ ɹɛskju hɪm? feɪn hæd bɪn pɑɹɾ ə ðə dɑɹk wʌnz skim tə faɪn hɪm. pɝhæps ɪt hæd sʌmθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðæt. ðən waɪ ɪz i ɹʌnɪŋ ɪnstɛɾ ə tʃeɪsɪŋ mi? ən wʌt kɪl ðət feɪd? wʌt hæpən ɪn ðət ɹum fʊl ə flaɪz? ən ðoʊz aɪz, wɑtʃɪŋ mi ɪn fæl dæɹə. ən ðət wɪnd, kætʃɪŋ mi laɪk ə biɾəl ɪn paɪn sæp. noʊ. noʊ, bælzəmən əz tə bi dɛd. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪd nɑt bɪliv ɪt. mɔɪɹeɪn dɪd nɑt bɪliv ɪt, nɔɹ ði æmɪɝlɪn. stʌbɝnli, hi ɹəfjuz tə θɪŋk əbaʊɾ ɪɾ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. ɔl i hæd tə θɪŋk əbaʊt naʊ wɑz faɪndɪŋ ðət dæɡɝ fəɹ mæt. faɪndɪŋ feɪn, ən ðə hɔɹn.

It seemed odd to him that he had begun to think of them as Fain's Darkfriends, Fain's Trollocs. Fain was just a madman. Then why did they rescue him? Fain had been part of the Dark One's scheme to find him. Perhaps it had something to do with that. Then why is he running instead of chasing me? And what killed that Fade? What happened in that room full of flies? And those eyes, watching me in Fal Dara. And that wind, catching me like a beetle in pine sap. No. No, Ba'alzamon has to be dead. The Aes Sedai did not believe it. Moiraine did not believe it, nor the Amyrlin. Stubbornly, he refused to think about it any longer. All he had to think about now was finding that dagger for Mat. Finding Fain, and the Horn.

ɪts nɛvɝ oʊvɝ, ælθɹ.

It's never over, al'Thor.

ðə vɔɪs wɑz laɪk ə θɪn bɹiz wɪspɝɪŋ ɪn ðə bæk ə hɪz hɛd, ə θɪn, aɪsi mɝmɝ wɝkɪŋ ɪts weɪ ɪndə ðə kɹɛvəsɪz ə hɪz maɪnd. hi ɔlmoʊst sɔt ðə vɔɪd tə ɪskeɪp ɪt, bʌt ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ wʌt weɪɾəd fəɹ ɪm ðɛɹ, hi pʊʃt daʊn ðə dɪzaɪɝ.

The voice was like a thin breeze whispering in the back of his head, a thin, icy murmur working its way into the crevices of his mind. He almost sought the void to escape it, but remembering what waited for him there, he pushed down the desire.

ɪn ðə hæf dɑɹk ə twaɪlaɪt, hi wɝk ðə fɔɹmz wɪð ɪz sɔɹd, ðə weɪ læn hæd tɔt, ðoʊ wɪθaʊt ðə vɔɪd. pɑɹɾɪŋ ðə sɪlk. hʌmɪŋbɝd kɪsəz ðə hʌniɹoʊz. hɛɹən weɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə ɹʌʃəz, fəɹ bæləns. luzɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ɪn ðə swɪft, ʃʊɹ muvməns, fɝɡɛɾɪŋ fəɹ ə taɪm wɛɹ i wɑz, hi wɝkt əntɪl swɛt kʌvɝd hɪm. jɛt wən i wɑz dʌn, ɪɾ ɔl keɪm bæk; nʌθɪŋ wɑz tʃeɪnʒd. ðə wɛðɝ wɑz nɑt koʊld, bʌɾ i ʃɪvɝɾ ən pʊld ɪz kloʊk ɝaʊn ɪm əz i hʌntʃt baɪ ðə faɪɝ. ði ʌðɝz kɑɾ ɪz mud, ən ðeɪ fɪnɪʃt iɾɪŋ kwɪkli ən ɪn saɪləns. noʊ wʌn kəmpleɪnd wən i kɪk dɝɾ oʊvɝ ðə læs fɪtfəl fleɪmz.

In the half dark of twilight, he worked the forms with his sword, the way Lan had taught, though without the void. Parting the Silk. Hummingbird Kisses the Honeyrose. Heron Wading in the Rushes, for balance. Losing himself in the swift, sure movements, forgetting for a time where he was, he worked until sweat covered him. Yet when he was done, it all came back; nothing was changed. The weather was not cold, but he shivered and pulled his cloak around him as he hunched by the fire. The others caught his mood, and they finished eating quickly and in silence. No one complained when he kicked dirt over the last fitful flames.

ɹænd tʊk ðə fɝst wɑtʃ hɪmsɛlf, wɔkɪŋ ði ɛdʒəz ə ðə kɑps wɪð ɪz baʊ, səmtaɪmz izɪŋ ɪz sɔɹɾ ɪn ɪts skæbɝd. ðə tʃɪl mun wɑz ɔlmoʊs fʊl, stændɪŋ haɪ ɪn ðə blæknəs, ən ðə naɪt wɑz əz saɪlən əz ðə deɪ hæd bɪn, əz ɛmpti. ɛmpti wɑz ðə ɹaɪt wɝd. ðə lænd wɑz əz ɛmpti əz ə dʌsti mɪlk kɹɑk. ɪt wɑz hɑɹd tə bɪliv ðəɹ wɑz ɛniwʌn ɪn ðə hoʊl wɝld, ɪn ðɪs wɝld, ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə θɹi ʌv ðɛm, hɑɹd tə bɪliv ivən ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz wɝ ðɛɹ, sʌmwɛɹ əhɛd.

Rand took the first watch himself, walking the edges of the copse with his bow, sometimes easing his sword in its scabbard. The chill moon was almost full, standing high in the blackness, and the night was as silent as the day had been, as empty. Empty was the right word. The land was as empty as a dusty milk crock. It was hard to believe there was anyone in the whole world, in this world, except for the three of them, hard to believe even the Darkfriends were there, somewhere ahead.

tə kip hɪmsɛlf kʌmpəni, hi ənɹæp tɑm mɛɹɪlɪnz kloʊk, ɪkspoʊzɪŋ ðə hɑɹp ən fluɾ ɪn ðɛɹ hɑɹd lɛðɝ keɪsəz ətɑp ðə mɛni-kʌlɝd pætʃəz. hi tʊk ðə ɡoʊld-ænd-sɪlvɝ flut fɹəm ɪts keɪs, ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ðə ɡlimən titʃɪŋ ɪm əz i fɪŋɡɝɾ ɪt, ən pleɪɾ ə fju noʊts ʌv "ðə wɪn ðət ʃeɪks ðə wɪloʊ," sɔfli soʊ əz nɑt tə weɪk ði ʌðɝz. ivən sɑft, ðə sæd saʊnd wɑz tu laʊɾ ɪn ðət pleɪs, tu ɹil. wɪð ə saɪ hi ɹipleɪs ðə fluɾ ən dɪɾ ʌp ðə bʌndəl əɡɛn.

To keep himself company, he unwrapped Thom Merrilin's cloak, exposing the harp and flute in their hard leather cases atop the many-colored patches. He took the gold-and-silver flute from its case, remembering the gleeman teaching him as he fingered it, and played a few notes of "The Wind That Shakes the Willow," softly so as not to wake the others. Even soft, the sad sound was too loud in that place, too real. With a sigh he replaced the flute and did up the bundle again.

hi hɛl ðə wɑtʃ lɔŋ ɪndə ðə naɪt, lɛɾɪŋ ði ʌðɝz slip. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ haʊ leɪɾ ɪt wɑz wən i sʌɾənli ɹilaɪzd ə fɑɡ hæd ɹɪzən. kloʊz tə ðə ɡɹaʊn ɪt leɪ, θɪk, meɪkɪŋ hʊɹɪn ən lɔɪəl ɪndɪstɪŋk maʊnz simɪŋ tə hʌmp aʊɾ ə klaʊdz. θɪnɝ haɪɝ ʌp, ɪt stɪl ʃɹaʊɾɪd ðə læn ɝaʊn ðɛm, haɪɾɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪksɛp ðə nɪɹəs tʃɹiz. ðə mun sim vjud θɹu wɔɾɝd sɪlk. ɛniθɪŋ əɾ ɔl kəd kʌm ɹaɪɾ ʌp tə ðɛm ənsin. hi tʌtʃt ɪz sɔɹd.

He held the watch long into the night, letting the others sleep. He did not know how late it was when he suddenly realized a fog had risen. Close to the ground it lay, thick, making Hurin and Loial indistinct mounds seeming to hump out of clouds. Thinner higher up, it still shrouded the land around them, hiding everything except the nearest trees. The moon seemed viewed through watered silk. Anything at all could come right up to them unseen. He touched his sword.

"sɔɹdz də noʊ ɡʊɾ əɡɛns mi, luz θɝɪn. jə ʃəd noʊ ðæt."

"Swords do no good against me, Lews Therin. You should know that."

ðə fɑɡ swɝld ɝaʊn ɹændz fiɾ əz i spʌn, ðə sɔɹd kʌmɪŋ ɪndə hɪz hænz, hɛɹən-mɑɹk bleɪɾ əpɹaɪt bɪfɔɹ hɪm. ðə vɔɪd lɛpt ʌp ɪnsaɪd hɪm; fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm, hi bɛɹli noʊɾəst ðə teɪntɪd laɪɾ ə seɪɾɪn.

The fog swirled around Rand's feet as he spun, the sword coming into his hands, heron-mark blade upright before him. The void leaped up inside him; for the first time, he barely noticed the tainted light of saidin.

ə ʃæɾoʊi fɪɡjɝ dʒɹu nɪɹɝ θɹu ðə mɪst, wɔkɪŋ wɪð ə tɔl stæf. bɪhaɪn ɪt, əz ɪf ðə ʃædoʊz ʃædoʊ wɝ væst, ðə fɑɡ dɑɹkən tɪl ɪt wɑz blækɝ ðən naɪt. ɹændz skɪn kɹɔld. kloʊsɝ ðə fɪɡjɝ keɪm, əntɪl ɪt ɹizɑlvd ɪndə ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ə mæn, kloʊðd ən ɡlʌvd ɪn blæk, wɪð ə blæk sɪlk mæsk kʌvɝɪŋ ɪz feɪs, ən ðə ʃædoʊ keɪm wɪð ɪt. hɪz stæf wɑz blæk, tu, əz ɪf ðə wʊd hæd bɪn tʃɑɹd, jɛt smuð ən ʃaɪnɪŋ laɪk wɔɾɝ baɪ munlaɪt. fəɹ ən ɪnstən ði aɪhoʊlz ə ðə mæsk ɡloʊd, əz ɪf faɪɝz stʊd bɪhaɪn əm ɹæðɝ ðən aɪz, bʌt ɹænd dɪd nɑt nid ðət tə noʊ hu ɪt wɑz.

A shadowy figure drew nearer through the mist, walking with a tall staff. Behind it, as if the shadow's shadow were vast, the fog darkened till it was blacker than night. Rand's skin crawled. Closer the figure came, until it resolved into the shape of a man, clothed and gloved in black, with a black silk mask covering his face, and the shadow came with it. His staff was black, too, as if the wood had been charred, yet smooth and shining like water by moonlight. For an instant the eyeholes of the mask glowed, as if fires stood behind them rather than eyes, but Rand did not need that to know who it was.

"bælzəmən," hi bɹiðd. "ðɪs ɪz ə dʒɹim. ɪts tə bi. aɪ fɛl əslip, ən - "

"Ba'alzamon," he breathed. "This is a dream. It has to be. I fell asleep, and - "

bælzəmən læf laɪk ðə ɹɔɹ ʌv ən oʊpən fɝnəs. "ju ɔlweɪz tʃɹaɪ tə dɪnaɪ wʌɾ ɪz, luz θɝɪn. ɪf aɪ stʃɹɛtʃ aʊt maɪ hænd, aɪ kən tʌtʃ ju, kɪnsleɪɝ. aɪ kən ɔlweɪz tʌtʃ ju. ɔlweɪz ən ɛvɹiwɛɹ."

Ba'alzamon laughed like the roar of an open furnace. "You always try to deny what is, Lews Therin. If I stretch out my hand, I can touch you, Kinslayer. I can always touch you. Always and everywhere."

"aɪ æm nɑt ðə dʒɹæɡən! maɪ neɪm ɪz ɹænd æl' - !" ɹænd klæmpt ɪz tiθ ʃʌt tə stɑp hɪmsɛlf.

"I am not the Dragon! My name is Rand al' - !" Rand clamped his teeth shut to stop himself.

"oʊ, aɪ noʊ ðə neɪm jə juz naʊ, luz θɝɪn. aɪ noʊ ɛvɹi neɪm juv juz θɹu eɪdʒ æftɝ eɪdʒ, lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ jə wɝ ivən ðə kɪnsleɪɝ." bælzəmənz vɔɪs bɪɡæn tə ɹaɪz ɪn ɪntɛnsəɾi; səmtaɪmz ðə faɪɝz ə hɪz aɪz flɛɹd soʊ haɪ ðət ɹænd kəd si ðɛm θɹu ði oʊpənɪŋz ɪn ðə sɪlk mæsk, si ðɛm laɪk ɛnləs siz ə fleɪm. "aɪ noʊ ju, noʊ jəɹ blʌɾ ən jəɹ laɪn bæk tə ðə fɝst spɑɹk ə laɪf ðəɾ ɛvɝ wɑz, bæk tə ðə fɝs moʊmənt. jə kən nɛvɝ haɪd fɹəm mi. nɛvɝ! wəɹ taɪd təɡɛðɝ əz ʃʊɹli əz tu saɪdz ə ðə seɪm kɔɪn. ɔɹɾənɛɹi mɛn meɪ haɪɾ ɪn ðə swip ə ðə pæɾɝn, bʌt tɑvɝən stæn aʊt laɪk bikən faɪɝz ɑn ə hɪl, ən ju, jə stæn aʊɾ əz ɪf tɛn θaʊzənd ʃaɪnɪŋ æɹoʊz stʊɾ ɪn ðə skaɪ tə pɔɪn jə aʊt! jə ɑɹ maɪn, ən ɛvɝ ɪn ɹitʃ ə maɪ hænd!"

"Oh, I know the name you use now, Lews Therin. I know every name you have used through Age after Age, long before you were even the Kinslayer." Ba'alzamon's voice began to rise in intensity; sometimes the fires of his eyes flared so high that Rand could see them through the openings in the silk mask, see them like endless seas of flame. "I know you, know your blood and your line back to the first spark of life that ever was, back to the First Moment. You can never hide from me. Never! We are tied together as surely as two sides of the same coin. Ordinary men may hide in the sweep of the Pattern, but ta'veren stand out like beacon fires on a hill, and you, you stand out as if ten thousand shining arrows stood in the sky to point you out! You are mine, and ever in reach of my hand!"

"fɑðɝ ə laɪz!" ɹænd mænədʒd. dɪspaɪt ðə vɔɪd, hɪz tʌŋ wɑntəd tə kliv tə ðə ɹuf ə hɪz maʊθ. laɪt, pliz lɛɾ ɪt bi ə dʒɹim. ðə θɔt skɪɾɝd aʊtsaɪd ði ɛmptinəs. ivən wʌn ə ðoʊz dʒɹimz ðəɾ ɪzən ə dʒɹim. hi kæn ɹɪli bi stændɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə mi. ðə dɑɹk wʌn ɪz sild ɪn ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl, sil baɪ ðə kɹieɪɾɝ ət ðə moʊmən ə kɹieɪʃən. . . . hi nu tu mʌtʃ ə ðə tʃɹuθ fəɹ ɪt tə hɛlp. "jɔɹ wɛl neɪmd! ɪf jə kəd dʒʌs teɪk mi, waɪ hævən ju? kəz jə kænɑt. aɪ wɔk ɪn ðə laɪt, ən jə kænɑt tʌtʃ mi!"

"Father of Lies!" Rand managed. Despite the void, his tongue wanted to cleave to the roof of his mouth. Light, please let it be a dream. The thought skittered outside the emptiness. Even one of those dreams that isn't a dream. He can't really be standing in front of me. The Dark One is sealed in Shayol Ghul, sealed by the Creator at the moment of Creation. . . . He knew too much of the truth for it to help. "You're well named! If you could just take me, why haven't you? Because you cannot. I walk in the Light, and you cannot touch me!"

bælzəmən lin ɑn ɪz stæf ən lʊkt ət ɹænd ə moʊmənt, ðən muv tə stæn oʊvɝ lɔɪəl ən hʊɹɪn, piɹɪŋ daʊn ət ðɛm. ðə væst ʃædoʊ muvd wɪð hɪm. hi dɪd nɑt dɪstɝb ðə fɑɡ, ɹænd sɔ - hi muvd, ðə stæf swʌŋ wɪð ɪz stɛps, bʌt ðə ɡɹeɪ mɪs dɪd nɑt swɝl ən ɛɾi ɝaʊn ɪz fiɾ əz ɪt dɪɾ ɝaʊn ɹænz. ðət ɡeɪv ɪm hɑɹt. pɝhæps bælzəmən ɹɪli wɑz nɑt ðɛɹ. pɝhæps ɪt wɑz ə dʒɹim.

Ba'alzamon leaned on his staff and looked at Rand a moment, then moved to stand over Loial and Hurin, peering down at them. The vast shadow moved with him. He did not disturb the fog, Rand saw - he moved, the staff swung with his steps, but the gray mist did not swirl and eddy around his feet as it did around Rand's. That gave him heart. Perhaps Ba'alzamon really was not there. Perhaps it was a dream.

"ju faɪn ɑd fɑloʊɝz," bælzəmən mjuzd. "ju ɔlweɪz dɪd. ðiz tu. ðə ɡɝl u tʃɹaɪz tə wɑtʃ oʊvɝ ju. ə pʊɹ ɡɑɹɾiən ən wik, kɪnsleɪɝ. ɪf ʃi hæɾ ə laɪftaɪm tə ɡɹoʊ, ʃi wəd nɛvɝ ɡɹoʊ stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf fəɹ jə tə haɪd bɪhaɪnd."

"You find odd followers," Ba'alzamon mused. "You always did. These two. The girl who tries to watch over you. A poor guardian and weak, Kinslayer. If she had a lifetime to grow, she would never grow strong enough for you to hide behind."

ɡɝl? hu? mɔɪɹeɪn ɪz ʃʊɹli nɑɾ ə ɡɝl. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt jə ɑɹ tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt, fɑðɝ ə laɪz. jə laɪ, ən laɪ, ən ivən wən jə tɛl ðə tʃɹuθ, jə twɪst ɪt tə ə laɪ."

Girl? Who? Moiraine is surely not a girl. "I don't know what you are talking about, Father of Lies. You lie, and lie, and even when you tell the truth, you twist it to a lie."

"du aɪ, luz θɝɪn? jə noʊ wʌt jə ɑɹ, hu jə ɑɹ. aɪ hæv toʊl ju. ən soʊ hæv ðoʊz wɪmən ə tɑɹ vəlɑn." ɹænd ʃɪftəd, ən bælzəmən ɡeɪv ə læf, laɪk ə smɔl θʌndɝklæp. "ðeɪ θɪŋk ðɛmsɛlvz seɪf ɪn ðɛɹ waɪt taʊɝ, bʌt maɪ fɑloʊɝz nʌmbɝ ivən səm ə ðɛɹ oʊn. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ kɔl mɔɪɹeɪn toʊl jə hu jə ɑɹ, dɪd ʃi nɑt? dɪd ʃi laɪ? əɹ ɪz ʃi wʌn ə maɪn? ðə waɪt taʊɝ minz tə juz jə laɪk ə haʊn ɑn ə liʃ. də aɪ laɪ? də aɪ laɪ wən aɪ seɪ jə sik ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ?" hi læft əɡɛn; kɑm ə ðə vɔɪɾ əɹ noʊ, ɪt wɑz ɔl ɹænd kəd də nɑt tə kʌvɝ ɪz ɪɹz. "səmtaɪmz oʊld ɛnəmiz faɪt soʊ lɔŋ ðət ðeɪ bɪkʌm ælaɪz ən nɛvɝ ɹilaɪz ɪt. ðeɪ θɪŋk ðeɪ stʃɹaɪk ət ju, bʌt ðeɪv bɪkʌm soʊ kloʊsli lɪŋkt ɪts əz ɪf jə ɡaɪɾəd ðə bloʊ jɝsɛlf."

"Do I, Lews Therin? You know what you are, who you are. I have told you. And so have those women of Tar Valon." Rand shifted, and Ba'alzamon gave a laugh, like a small thunderclap. "They think themselves safe in their White Tower, but my followers number even some of their own. The Aes Sedai called Moiraine told you who you are, did she not? Did she lie? Or is she one of mine? The White Tower means to use you like a hound on a leash. Do I lie? Do I lie when I say you seek the Horn of Valere?" He laughed again; calm of the void or no, it was all Rand could do not to cover his ears. "Sometimes old enemies fight so long that they become allies and never realize it. They think they strike at you, but they have become so closely linked it is as if you guided the blow yourself."

"ju doʊnt ɡaɪd mi," ɹænd sɛd. "aɪ dɪnaɪ ju."

"You don't guide me," Rand said. "I deny you."

"aɪ hæv ə θaʊzən stʃɹɪŋz taɪd tə ju, kɪnsleɪɝ, itʃ wʌn faɪnɝ ðən sɪlk ən stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən stil. taɪm əz taɪɾ ə θaʊzən kɔɹdz bɪtwin ʌs. ðə bæɾəl wi tu hæv fɔt - dʒju ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɛni pɑɹɾ ə ðæt? juv ɛni ɡlɪmɝɪŋ ðət wɪv fɔt bɪfɔɹ, bæɾəlz wɪθaʊt nʌmbɝ bæk tə ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ ə taɪm? aɪ noʊ mʌtʃ ðət jə də nɑt! ðət bæɾəl wɪl sun ɛnd. ðə læs bæɾəl ɪz kʌmɪŋ. ðə læst, luz θɝɪn. dʒju ɹɪli θɪŋk jə kən əvɔɪɾ ɪt? jə pʊɹ, ʃɪvɝɪŋ wɝm. jəl sɝv mi əɹ daɪ! ən ðɪs taɪm ðə saɪkəl wɪl nɑt bɪɡɪn ənu wɪð jəɹ dɛθ. ðə ɡɹeɪv bɪlɔŋz tə ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ ə ðə dɑɹk. ðɪs taɪm ɪf jə daɪ, jəl bi dɪstʃɹɔɪɾ ʌɾɝli. ðɪs taɪm ðə wil wɪl bi bɹoʊkən wʌtɛvɝ jə du, ən ðə wɝld ɹimeɪd tə ə nu moʊld. sɝv mi! sɝv ʃeɪtɑn, əɹ bi dɪstʃɹɔɪd fɝɛvɝ!"

"I have a thousand strings tied to you, Kinslayer, each one finer than silk and stronger than steel. Time has tied a thousand cords between us. The battle we two have fought - do you remember any part of that? Do you have any glimmering that we have fought before, battles without number back to the beginning of Time? I know much that you do not! That battle will soon end. The Last Battle is coming. The last, Lews Therin. Do you really think you can avoid it? You poor, shivering worm. You will serve me or die! And this time the cycle will not begin anew with your death. The grave belongs to the Great Lord of the Dark. This time if you die, you will be destroyed utterly. This time the Wheel will be broken whatever you do, and the world remade to a new mold. Serve me! Serve Shai'tan, or be destroyed forever!"

wɪð ði ʌɾɝəns ə ðət neɪm, ði ɛɹ sim tə θɪkən. ðə dɑɹknəs bɪhaɪn bælzəmən swɛld ən ɡɹu, θɹɛɾənɪŋ tə swɑloʊ ɛvɹiθɪŋ. ɹænd fɛlt ɪɾ ɪnɡʌlfɪŋ hɪm, koʊldɝ ðən aɪs ən hɑɾɝ ðən koʊlz boʊθ ət ðə seɪm taɪm, blækɝ ðən dɛθ, sʌkɪŋ ɪm ɪndə ðə dɛpθs ʌv ɪt, oʊvɝwɛlmɪŋ ðə wɝld.

With the utterance of that name, the air seemed to thicken. The darkness behind Ba'alzamon swelled and grew, threatening to swallow everything. Rand felt it engulfing him, colder than ice and hotter than coals both at the same time, blacker than death, sucking him into the depths of it, overwhelming the world.

hi ɡɹɪpt ɪz sɔɹd hɪl tɪl ɪz nʌkəlz hɝt. "aɪ dɪnaɪ ju, ən aɪ dɪnaɪ jəɹ paʊɝ. aɪ wɔk ɪn ðə laɪt. ðə laɪt pɹəzɝvz ʌs, ən wi ʃɛltɝ ɪn ðə pɑm ə ðə kɹieɪɾɝz hænd." hi blɪŋkt. bælzəmən stɪl stʊd ðɛɹ, ən ðə ɡɹeɪt dɑɹknəs stɪl hʌŋ bɪhaɪn hɪm, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz əz ɪf ɔl ðə ɹɛs hæd bɪn ɪluʒən.

He gripped his sword hilt till his knuckles hurt. "I deny you, and I deny your power. I walk in the Light. The Light preserves us, and we shelter in the palm of the Creator's hand." He blinked. Ba'alzamon still stood there, and the great darkness still hung behind him, but it was as if all the rest had been illusion.

"du jə wɑnə si maɪ feɪs?" ɪt wɑz ə wɪspɝ.

"Do you want to see my face?" It was a whisper.

ɹænd swɑloʊd. "noʊ."

Rand swallowed. "No."

"ju ʃʊd." ə ɡlʌv hænd wɛn tə ðə blæk mæsk.

"You should." A gloved hand went to the black mask.

"noʊ!"

"No!"

ðə mæsk keɪm əweɪ. ɪt wɑz ə mænz feɪs, hɔɹəbli bɝnd. jɛt bɪtwin ðə blæk-ɛdʒd, ɹɛd kɹɛvəsɪz kɹɔsɪŋ ðoʊz fitʃɝz, ðə skɪn lʊk hɛlθi ən smuð. dɑɹk aɪz lʊkt ət ɹænd; kɹuəl lɪps smaɪld wɪð ə flæʃ ʌv waɪt tiθ. "lʊk ət mi, kɪnsleɪɝ, ən si ðə hʌnʒɹədθ pɑɹɾ ə jəɹ oʊn feɪt." fəɹ ə moʊmən aɪz ən maʊθ bɪkeɪm dɔɹweɪz ɪndə ɛnləs kævɝnz ə faɪɝ. "ðɪs ɪz wʌt ðə paʊɝ əntʃɛkt kən du, ivən tə mi. bʌɾ aɪ hil, luz θɝɪn. aɪ noʊ ðə pæðz tə ɡɹeɪɾɝ paʊɝ. ɪɾəl bɝn jə laɪk ə mɔθ flaɪɪŋ ɪndə ə fɝnəs."

The mask came away. It was a man's face, horribly burned. Yet between the black-edged, red crevices crossing those features, the skin looked healthy and smooth. Dark eyes looked at Rand; cruel lips smiled with a flash of white teeth. "Look at me, Kinslayer, and see the hundredth part of your own fate." For a moment eyes and mouth became doorways into endless caverns of fire. "This is what the Power unchecked can do, even to me. But I heal, Lews Therin. I know the paths to greater power. It will burn you like a moth flying into a furnace."

"aɪ wɪl nɑt tʌtʃ ɪt!" ɹænd fɛl ðə vɔɪɾ ɝaʊn hɪm, fɛl seɪɾɪn. "aɪ woʊnt."

"I will not touch it!" Rand felt the void around him, felt saidin. "I won't."

"ju kænɑt stɑp jɝsɛlf."

"You cannot stop yourself."

"liv - mi - əloʊn!"

"Leave - me - ALONE!"

"paʊɝ." bælzəmənz vɔɪs bɪkeɪm sɑft, ɪnsɪnjueɪɾɪŋ. "ju kən əv paʊɝ əɡɛn, luz θɝɪn. jə ɑɹ lɪŋk tə ɪt naʊ, ðɪs moʊmənt. aɪ noʊ ɪt. aɪ kən si ɪt. fil ɪt, luz θɝɪn. fil ðə ɡloʊ ɪnsaɪd ju. fil ðə paʊɝ ðət kəd bi jʊɹz. ɔl jə mʌs də ɪz ɹitʃ aʊt fəɹ ɪt. bʌt ðə ʃædoʊ ɪz ðəɹ bɪtwin jə ən ɪt. mædnəs ən dɛθ. jə nid nɑt daɪ, luz θɝɪn, nɑɾ ɛvɝ əɡɛn."

"Power." Ba'alzamon's voice became soft, insinuating. "You can have power again, Lews Therin. You are linked to it now, this moment. I know it. I can see it. Feel it, Lews Therin. Feel the glow inside you. Feel the power that could be yours. All you must do is reach out for it. But the Shadow is there between you and it. Madness and death. You need not die, Lews Therin, not ever again."

"noʊ," ɹænd sɛd, bʌt ðə vɔɪs wɛn ɑn, bɝoʊɪŋ ɪndə hɪm.

"No," Rand said, but the voice went on, burrowing into him.

"aɪ kən titʃ jə tə kəntʃɹoʊl ðət paʊɝ soʊ ðəɾ ɪt dʌz nɑt dɪstʃɹɔɪ ju. noʊ wʌn ɛls laɪvz u kən titʃ jə ðæt. ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ ə ðə dɑɹk kən ʃɛltɝ jə fɹəm ðə mædnəs. ðə paʊɝ kən bi jʊɹz, ən jə kən lɪv fɝɛvɝ. fɝɛvɝ! ɔl jə mʌs də ɪn ɹɪtɝn ɪz sɝv. oʊnli sɝv. sɪmpəl wɝdz - aɪm jʊɹz, ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd - ən paʊɝ wɪl bi jʊɹz. paʊɝ bɪɑn ɛniθɪŋ ðoʊz wɪmən ə tɑɹ vəlɑn dʒɹim ʌv, ən laɪf ɪtɝnəl, ɪf jəl oʊnli ɔfɝ jɝsɛlf ʌp ən sɝv."

"I can teach you to control that power so that it does not destroy you. No one else lives who can teach you that. The Great Lord of the Dark can shelter you from the madness. The power can be yours, and you can live forever. Forever! All you must do in return is serve. Only serve. Simple words - I am yours, Great Lord - and power will be yours. Power beyond anything those women of Tar Valon dream of, and life eternal, if you will only offer yourself up and serve."

ɹænd lɪkt ɪz lɪps. nɑt tə ɡoʊ mæd. nɑt tə daɪ. "nɛvɝ! aɪ wɔk ɪn ðə laɪt," hi ɡɹeɪɾɪd hɔɹsli, "æn jə kən nɛvɝ tʌtʃ mi!"

Rand licked his lips. Not to go mad. Not to die. "Never! I walk in the Light," he grated hoarsely, "and you can never touch me!"

"tʌtʃ ju, luz θɝɪn? tʌtʃ ju? aɪ kən kənsum ju! teɪst ɪɾ ən noʊ, əz aɪ nu!"

"Touch you, Lews Therin? Touch you? I can consume you! Taste it and know, as I knew!"

ðoʊz dɑɹk aɪz bɪkeɪm faɪɝ əɡɛn, ən ðət maʊθ, fleɪm ðət blɑsəmd ən ɡɹu əntɪl ɪt sim bɹaɪɾɝ ðən ə sʌmɝ sʌn. ɡɹu, ən sʌɾənli ɹændz sɔɹd ɡloʊɾ əz ɪf dʒʌs dʒɹɔn fɹəm ðə fɔɹdʒ. hi kɹaɪɾ aʊɾ əz ðə hɪl bɝn ɪz hænz, skɹimd ən dʒɹɑp ðə sɔɹd. ən ðə fɑɡ kɑt faɪɝ, faɪɝ ðət lɛpt, faɪɝ ðət bɝn ɛvɹiθɪŋ.

Those dark eyes became fire again, and that mouth, flame that blossomed and grew until it seemed brighter than a summer sun. Grew, and suddenly Rand's sword glowed as if just drawn from the forge. He cried out as the hilt burned his hands, screamed and dropped the sword. And the fog caught fire, fire that leaped, fire that burned everything.

jɛlɪŋ, ɹænd biɾ əɾ ɪz kloʊðz əz ðeɪ smoʊkt ən tʃɑɹɾ ən fɛl ɪn æʃəz, bit wɪð hænz ðət blækən ən ʃɹɪvəld əz neɪkəd flɛʃ kɹækt ən pild əweɪ ɪn ðə fleɪmz. hi skɹimd. peɪn biɾ ət ðə vɔɪɾ ɪnsaɪd hɪm, ən i tʃɹaɪd tə kɹɔl dipɝ ɪndə ði ɛmptinəs. ðə ɡloʊ wɑz ðɛɹ, ðə teɪntɪd laɪt dʒʌst aʊɾ ə saɪt. hæf mæd, noʊ lɔŋɡɝ kɛɹɪŋ wʌɾ ɪt wɑz, hi ɹitʃt fəɹ seɪɾɪn, tʃɹaɪd tə ɹæp ɪɾ ɝaʊn hɪm, tʃɹaɪd tə haɪɾ ɪn ɪt fɹəm ðə bɝnɪŋ ən ðə peɪn.

Yelling, Rand beat at his clothes as they smoked and charred and fell in ashes, beat with hands that blackened and shriveled as naked flesh cracked and peeled away in the flames. He screamed. Pain beat at the void inside him, and he tried to crawl deeper into the emptiness. The glow was there, the tainted light just out of sight. Half mad, no longer caring what it was, he reached for saidin, tried to wrap it around him, tried to hide in it from the burning and the pain.

əz sʌɾənli əz ðə faɪɝ bɪɡæn, ɪt wɑz ɡɔn. ɹænd stɛɹd wʌndɝɪŋli əɾ ɪz hæn stɪkɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə ɹɛd sliv ə hɪz koʊt. ðəɹ wɑz nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə sɪnʒ ɑn ðə wʊl. aɪ ɪmædʒən ɪɾ ɔl. fɹæntəkəli, hi lʊkt ɝaʊnd. bælzəmən wɑz ɡɔn. hʊɹɪn ʃɪftəɾ ɪn ɪz slip; ðə snɪfɝ ən lɔɪəl wɝ stɪl oʊnli tu maʊnz stɪkɪŋ ʌp aʊɾ ə ðə loʊ fɑɡ. aɪ dɪɾ ɪmædʒən ɪt.

As suddenly as the fire began, it was gone. Rand stared wonderingly at his hand sticking out of the red sleeve of his coat. There was not so much as a singe on the wool. I imagined it all. Frantically, he looked around. Ba'alzamon was gone. Hurin shifted in his sleep; the sniffer and Loial were still only two mounds sticking up out of the low fog. I did imagine it.

bɪfɔɹ ɹɪlif hæɾ ə tʃæns tə ɡɹoʊ, peɪn stæbd ɪz ɹaɪt hænd, ən i tɝn ɪɾ ʌp tə lʊk. ðəɹ əkɹɔs ðə pɑm wɑz bɹændɪɾ ə hɛɹən. ðə hɛɹən fɹəm ðə hɪlt ə hɪz sɔɹd, æŋɡɹi ən ɹɛd, əz nitli dʌn əz ðoʊ dʒɹɔn wɪð ən ɑɹɾəsts skɪl.

Before relief had a chance to grow, pain stabbed his right hand, and he turned it up to look. There across the palm was branded a heron. The heron from the hilt of his sword, angry and red, as neatly done as though drawn with an artist's skill.

fʌmbəlɪŋ ə kɝtʃəf fɹəm ɪz koʊt pɑkət, hi ɹæpt ɪɾ ɝaʊn ɪz hænd. ðə hæn θɹɑbd, naʊ. ðə vɔɪd wəd hɛlp wɪð ðət - hi wɑz əwɛɹ ə peɪn ɪn ðə vɔɪd, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt fil ɪt - bʌɾ i pʊt ðə θɔɾ aʊɾ ə hɪz hɛd. twaɪs naʊ, ənnoʊɪŋ - ən wʌns ɑn pɝpəs; hi kəd nɑt fɝɡɛt ðət - hi hæd tʃɹaɪd tə tʃænəl ðə wʌn paʊɝ waɪl i wɑz ɪn ðə vɔɪd. ɪt wɑz wɪð ðət ðət bælzəmən wɑntəd tə tɛmp hɪm. ɪt wɑz ðət ðət mɔɪɹeɪn ən ði æmɪɝlɪn sit wɑntəɾ ɪm tə du. hi wəd nɑt.

Fumbling a kerchief from his coat pocket, he wrapped it around his hand. The hand throbbed, now. The void would help with that - he was aware of pain in the void, but he did not feel it - but he put the thought out of his head. Twice now, unknowing - and once on purpose; he could not forget that - he had tried to channel the One Power while he was in the void. It was with that that Ba'alzamon wanted to tempt him. It was that that Moiraine and the Amyrlin Seat wanted him to do. He would not.


tʃæptɝ sɪkstin


CHAPTER 16

ɪn ðə mɪɹɝ ə dɑɹknəs


In the Mirror of Darkness

"ju ʃəd nɑɾ əv dʌn ɪt, lɔɹd ɹænd," hʊɹɪn sɛd wən ɹænd woʊk ði ʌðɝz dʒʌst ət deɪbɹeɪk. ðə sʌn jɛt hɪd bɪloʊ ðə hɝaɪzən, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz laɪɾ ɪnʌf tə si. ðə fɑɡ hæd mɛltəɾ əweɪ waɪl dɑɹk stɪl hɛld, feɪɾɪŋ ɹɪlʌktənli. "ɪf jə jus jɝsɛlf ʌp tə spɛɹ ʌs, maɪ lɔɹd, hu wɪl si tə ɡɛɾɪŋ əs hoʊm?"

"You should not have done it, Lord Rand," Hurin said when Rand woke the others just at daybreak. The sun yet hid below the horizon, but there was light enough to see. The fog had melted away while dark still held, fading reluctantly. "If you use yourself up to spare us, my Lord, who will see to getting us home?"

"aɪ niɾəd tə θɪŋk," ɹænd sɛd. nʌθɪŋ ʃoʊd ðə fɑɡ hæɾ ɛvɝ bɪn, əɹ bælzəmən. hi fɪŋɡɝd ðə kɝtʃəf ɹæpt ɝaʊn ɪz ɹaɪt hænd. ðəɹ wɑz ðət tə pɹuv bælzəmən hæd bɪn ðɛɹ. hi wɑntəd tə bi əweɪ fɹəm ðɪs pleɪs. "taɪm tə bi ɪn ðə sæɾəl ɪf wəɹ gɑnə kætʃ feɪnz dɑɹkfɹɛnz. pæs taɪm. wi kən it flætbɹɛd waɪl wi ɹaɪd."

"I needed to think," Rand said. Nothing showed the fog had ever been, or Ba'alzamon. He fingered the kerchief wrapped around his right hand. There was that to prove Ba'alzamon had been there. He wanted to be away from this place. "Time to be in the saddle if we are going to catch Fain's Darkfriends. Past time. We can eat flatbread while we ride."

lɔɪəl pɔzd ɪn ði ækt ə stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ, hɪz ɑɹmz ɹitʃɪŋ əz haɪ əz hʊɹɪn cʊɾə stændɪŋ ɑn ɹændz ʃoʊldɝz. "jɔɹ hænd, ɹænd. wʌt hæpənd?"

Loial paused in the act of stretching, his arms reaching as high as Hurin could have standing on Rand's shoulders. "Your hand, Rand. What happened?"

"aɪ hɝɾ ɪt. ɪts nʌθɪŋ."

"I hurt it. It's nothing."

"aɪ hæv ə sɑv ɪn maɪ sæɾəlbæɡz - "

"I have a salve in my saddlebags - "

"ɪɾ ɪz nʌθɪŋ!" ɹænd nu hi saʊndəd hɑɹʃ, bʌt wʌn lʊk ət ðə bɹænd wəd ʃʊɹli bɹɪŋ kwɛstʃənz i dɪd nɑt wɑnə ænsɝ. "taɪmz weɪstɪŋ. lɛɾ əs bi ɑn əɹ weɪ." hi sɛɾ əbaʊt sæɾəlɪŋ ɹɛd, ɔkwɝdli kəz ə hɪz ɪnʒɝd hænd, ən hʊɹɪn dʒʌmp tə hɪz oʊn hɔɹs.

"It is nothing!" Rand knew he sounded harsh, but one look at the brand would surely bring questions he did not want to answer. "Time's wasting. Let us be on our way." He set about saddling Red, awkwardly because of his injured hand, and Hurin jumped to his own horse.

"noʊ nid tə bi soʊ tʌtʃi," lɔɪəl mʌɾɝd.

"No need to be so touchy," Loial muttered.

ə tʃɹæk, ɹænd dɪsaɪɾɪd əz ðeɪ sɛɾ aʊt, wəd bi sʌmθɪŋ nætʃɹəl ɪn ðət wɝld. ðəɹ wɝ tu mɛni ənnætʃɹəl θɪŋz ðɛɹ. ivən ə sɪŋɡəl hʊfpɹɪnt wəd bi wɛlkəm. feɪn ən ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz ən ðə tʃɹɑləks hæd tə liv səm mɑɹk. hi kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾəd ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn ðeɪ pæst oʊvɝ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk aʊɾ ɛni tʃɹeɪs ðət cʊɾə bɪn meɪd baɪ ənʌðɝ lɪvɪŋ θɪŋ.

A track, Rand decided as they set out, would be something natural in that world. There were too many unnatural things there. Even a single hoofprint would be welcome. Fain and the Darkfriends and the Trollocs had to leave some mark. He concentrated on the ground they passed over, trying to make out any trace that could have been made by another living thing.

ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ, nɑɾ ə tɝn stoʊn, nɑɾ ə dɪstɝb klɑɾ ə ɝθ. wʌns i lʊkt ət ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪhaɪn ðɛm, dʒʌs tə ɹiəʃʊɹ hɪmsɛlf ðət ðə læn dɪd teɪk hʊfpɹɪns; skɹeɪp tɝf ən bɛnt ɡɹæs mɑɹk ðɛɹ pæsədʒ pleɪnli, jɛɾ əhɛd ðə ɡɹaʊnd wɑz ʌndɪstɝbd. bʌt hʊɹɪn ɪnsɪstəɾ i kəd smɛl ðə tʃɹeɪl, feɪn ən θɪn, bʌt stɪl hɛɾɪŋ saʊθ.

There was nothing, not a turned stone, not a disturbed clod of earth. Once he looked at the ground behind them, just to reassure himself that the land did take hoofprints; scraped turf and bent grass marked their passage plainly, yet ahead the ground was undisturbed. But Hurin insisted he could smell the trail, faint and thin, but still heading south.

wʌns əɡɛn ðə snɪfɝ pʊɾ ɔl ɪz ətɛnʃənz ɑn ðə tʃɹeɪl i fɑloʊd, laɪk ə haʊn tʃɹækɪŋ dɪɹ, ən wʌns əɡɛn lɔɪəl ɹoʊd lɔst ɪn ɪz oʊn θɔts, mʌɾɝɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf ən ɹʌbɪŋ ðə hjudʒ kɔɹɾɝstæf hɛld əkɹɔs ɪz sæɾəl ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm.

Once again the sniffer put all his attentions on the trail he followed, like a hound tracking deer, and once again Loial rode lost in his own thoughts, muttering to himself and rubbing the huge quarterstaff held across his saddle in front of him.

ðeɪ hæd nɑt bɪn ɹaɪɾɪŋ mɔɹ ðən ən aʊɝ wən ɹænd sɔ ðə spaɪɹ əhɛd. hi wɑz soʊ bɪzi wɑtʃɪŋ fəɹ tʃɹæks ðət ðə teɪpɝɪŋ kɑləm ɔlɹɛɾi stʊd θɪk ən tɔl əbʌv ðə tʃɹiz ɪn ðə mɪɾəl dɪstəns wən i fɝs noʊɾəst ɪt. "aɪ wʌndɝ wʌt ðəɾ ɪz." ɪt leɪ dɝɛkli ɪn ðɛɹ pæθ.

They had not been riding more than an hour when Rand saw the spire ahead. He was so busy watching for tracks that the tapering column already stood thick and tall above the trees in the middle distance when he first noticed it. "I wonder what that is." It lay directly in their path.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌɾ ɪt kən bi, ɹænd," lɔɪəl sɛd.

"I don't know what it can be, Rand," Loial said.

"ɪf ðɪs - ɪf ðɪs wɑz əɹ oʊn wɝld, lɔɹd ɹænd. . . ." hʊɹɪn ʃɪftəɾ ənkʌmftəbli ɪn ɪz sæɾəl. "wɛl, ðət mɑnjəmən lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹ wɑz tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt - ðə wʌn tə ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz vɪktɝi oʊvɝ ðə tʃɹɑləks - ɪt wɑz ə ɡɹeɪt spaɪɹ. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz tɔɹn daʊn ə θaʊzən jɪɹz əɡoʊ. ðɛɹz nʌθɪŋ lɛf bʌɾ ə bɪɡ maʊnd, laɪk ə hɪl. aɪ sɔ ɪt, wən aɪ wɛn tə kɛɹhin fəɹ lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ."

"If this - if this was our own world, Lord Rand. . . ." Hurin shifted uncomfortably in his saddle. "Well, that monument Lord Ingtar was talking about - the one to Artur Hawkwing's victory over the Trollocs - it was a great spire. But it was torn down a thousand years ago. There's nothing left but a big mound, like a hill. I saw it, when I went to Cairhien for Lord Agelmar."

"əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ɪŋtʃɹ," lɔɪəl sɛd, "ðæɾ ɪz stɪl θɹi əɹ fɔɹ deɪz əhɛɾ ʌv ʌs. ɪf ɪts hɪɹ əɾ ɔl. aɪ doʊnt noʊ waɪ ɪt ʃəd bi. aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðəɹ ɑɹ ɛni pipəl hɪɹ əɾ ɔl."

"According to Ingtar," Loial said, "that is still three or four days ahead of us. If it is here at all. I don't know why it should be. I don't think there are any people here at all."

ðə snɪfɝ pʊɾ ɪz aɪz bæk ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. "ðæts dʒʌst ɪt, ɪzən ɪt, bɪldɝ? noʊ pipəl, bʌt ðəɹ ɪts əhɛɾ ʌv ʌs. meɪbi wi ɔt tə kip klɪɹ ʌv ɪt, maɪ lɔɹd ɹænd. noʊ tɛlɪŋ wʌɾ ɪɾ ɪz, əɹ huz ðɛɹ, ɪn ə pleɪs laɪk ðɪs."

The sniffer put his eyes back on the ground. "That's just it, isn't it, Builder? No people, but there it is ahead of us. Maybe we ought to keep clear of it, my Lord Rand. No telling what it is, or who's there, in a place like this."

ɹænd dʒɹʌmd ɪz fɪŋɡɝz ɑn ðə haɪ pɑməl ə hɪz sæɾəl fəɹ ə moʊmənt, θɪŋkɪŋ. "wi hæv tə stɪk əz kloʊs tə ðə tʃɹeɪl əz wi kæn," hi sɛd faɪnəli. "wi doʊn sim tə bi ɡɛɾɪŋ ɛni kloʊsɝ tə feɪn əz ɪɾ ɪz, ən aɪ doʊnt wɑnə luz mɔɹ taɪm, ɪf wi kən əvɔɪɾ ɪt. ɪf wi si ɛni pipəl, əɹ ɛniθɪŋ aʊɾ ə ði ɔɹɾənɛɹi, ðən wɪl sɝkəl ɝaʊn əntɪl wi pɪk ɪɾ ʌp əɡɛn. bʌɾ əntɪl ðɛn, wi kip ɑn."

Rand drummed his fingers on the high pommel of his saddle for a moment, thinking. "We have to stick as close to the trail as we can," he said finally. "We don't seem to be getting any closer to Fain as it is, and I don't want to lose more time, if we can avoid it. If we see any people, or anything out of the ordinary, then we'll circle around until we pick it up again. But until then, we keep on."

"æz jə seɪ, maɪ lɔɹd." ðə snɪfɝ saʊndəɾ ɑd, ən i ɡeɪv ɹænd ə kwɪk, saɪɾɛlɔŋ lʊk. "æz jə seɪ."

"As you say, my Lord." The sniffer sounded odd, and he gave Rand a quick, sidelong look. "As you say."

ɹænd fɹaʊn fəɹ ə moʊmən bɪfɔɹ i ʌndɝstʊd, ən ðən ɪt wɑz ɪz tɝn tə saɪ. lɔɹdz dɪd nɑɾ ɪkspleɪn tə ðoʊz u fɑloʊd ðɛm, oʊnli tə ʌðɝ lɔɹdz. aɪ dɪdn æsk ɪm tə teɪk mi fəɹ ə blʌɾi lɔɹd. bʌɾ i dɪd, ə smɔl vɔɪs sim tə ænsɝ hɪm, ən jə lɛt hɪm. jə meɪd ðə tʃɔɪs; naʊ ðə duɾi ɪz jʊɹz.

Rand frowned for a moment before he understood, and then it was his turn to sigh. Lords did not explain to those who followed them, only to other lords. I didn't ask him to take me for a bloody lord. But he did, a small voice seemed to answer him, and you let him. You made the choice; now the duty is yours.

"teɪk ðə tʃɹeɪl, hʊɹɪn," ɹænd sɛd.

"Take the trail, Hurin," Rand said.

wɪð ə flæʃ ə ɹɪlivd ɡɹɪn, ðə snɪfɝ hild ɪz hɔɹs ɔnwɝd.

With a flash of relieved grin, the sniffer heeled his horse onward.

ðə wik sʌn klaɪmd əz ðeɪ ɹoʊd, ən baɪ ðə taɪm ɪt wɑz oʊvɝhɛd, ðeɪ wɝ oʊnli ə maɪl əɹ soʊ fɹəm ðə spaɪɹ. ðeɪ hæd ɹitʃt wʌn ə ðə stʃɹimz, ɪn ə ɡʌli ə peɪs dip, ən ði ɪntɝvinɪŋ tʃɹiz wɝ spɑɹs. ɹænd kəd si ðə maʊn ɪt wɑz bɪlt ɑn, laɪk ə ɹaʊnd, flæt-tɑp hɪl. ðə ɡɹeɪ spaɪɹ ɪtsɛlf ɹoʊz ət list ə hʌnʒɹəd spænz, ən i kəd dʒʌs meɪk aʊt naʊ ðət ðə tɑp wɑz kɑɹvd ɪn ðə laɪknəs ʌv ə bɝd wɪð aʊtstʃɹɛtʃt wɪŋz.

The weak sun climbed as they rode, and by the time it was overhead, they were only a mile or so from the spire. They had reached one of the streams, in a gully a pace deep, and the intervening trees were sparse. Rand could see the mound it was built on, like a round, flat-topped hill. The gray spire itself rose at least a hundred spans, and he could just make out now that the top was carved in the likeness of a bird with outstretched wings.

"ə hɔk," ɹænd sɛd. "ɪɾ ɪz hɔkwɪŋz mɑnjəmənt. ɪt mʌs bi. ðəɹ wɝ pipəl hɪɹ, wɛðɝ ðəɹ ɑɹ naʊ əɹ nɑt. ðeɪ dʒʌs bɪlt ɪɾ ɪn ənʌðɝ pleɪs hɪɹ, ən nɛvɝ tɔɹ ɪt daʊn. θɪŋk ʌv ɪt, hʊɹɪn. wən wi ɡɛt bæk, jəl bi eɪbəl tə tɛl əm wʌt ðə mɑnjəmən ɹɪli lʊk laɪk. ðəɹ wɪl oʊnli bi θɹi ʌv əs ɪn ðə hoʊl wɝld u hæv ɛvɝ sin ɪt."

"A hawk," Rand said. "It is Hawkwing's monument. It must be. There were people here, whether there are now or not. They just built it in another place here, and never tore it down. Think of it, Hurin. When we get back, you'll be able to tell them what the monument really looked like. There will only be three of us in the whole world who have ever seen it."

hʊɹɪn nɑɾəd. "jɛs, maɪ lɔɹd. maɪ tʃɪlʒɹən wəd laɪk tə hɪɹ ðət teɪl, ðɛɹ fɑðɝ siɪŋ hɔkwɪŋz spaɪɹ."

Hurin nodded. "Yes, my Lord. My children would like to hear that tale, their father seeing Hawkwing's spire."

"ɹænd," lɔɪəl bɪɡæn wɝidli.

"Rand," Loial began worriedly.

"wi kən ɡæləp ðə dɪstəns," ɹænd sɛd. "kʌm ɑn. ə ɡæləp wɪl də əs ɡʊd. ðɪs pleɪs meɪ bi dɛd, bʌt wɝ əlaɪv."

"We can gallop the distance," Rand said. "Come on. A gallop will do us good. This place may be dead, but we're alive."

"ɹænd," lɔɪəl sɛd, "aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðəɾ ɪz ə - "

"Rand," Loial said, "I don't think that is a - "

nɑt weɪɾɪŋ tə hɪɹ, ɹænd dʌɡ hɪz buts ɪndə ɹɛdz flæŋks, ən ðə stæljən spɹæŋ fɔɹwɝd. hi splæʃt əkɹɔs ðə ʃæloʊ ɹɪbən ʌv wɔɾɝ ɪn tu stʃɹaɪdz, ðən skɹæbəld ʌp ðə fɑɹ saɪd. hʊɹɪn lɔntʃt ɪz hɔɹs ɹaɪt bɪhaɪn hɪm. ɹænd hɝd lɔɪəl kɔlɪŋ bɪhaɪn ðɛm, bʌɾ i læft, weɪv fəɹ ði oʊɡiɝ tə fɑloʊ, ən ɡæləpt ɑn. ɪf i kɛpt ɪz aɪz ɑn wʌn spɑt, ðə læn dɪd nɑt sim tə slɪp ən slaɪd soʊ bædli, ən ðə wɪn fɛlt ɡʊɾ ɑn ɪz feɪs.

Not waiting to hear, Rand dug his boots into Red's flanks, and the stallion sprang forward. He splashed across the shallow ribbon of water in two strides, then scrabbled up the far side. Hurin launched his horse right behind him. Rand heard Loial calling behind them, but he laughed, waved for the Ogier to follow, and galloped on. If he kept his eyes on one spot, the land did not seem to slip and slide so badly, and the wind felt good on his face.

ðə maʊn kʌvɝɾ ə ɡʊd tu haɪdz, bʌt ðə ɡɹæsi sloʊp ɹoʊz əɾ ən izi slænt. ðə ɡɹeɪ spaɪɹ ɹɪɹɾ ɪndə ðə skaɪ, skwɛɹɾ ən bɹɔɾ ɪnʌf dɪspaɪɾ ɪts haɪt tə sim mæsɪv, ɔlmoʊst skwɑt. ɹændz læftɝ daɪd, ən i pʊld ɹɛɾ ʌp, hɪz feɪs ɡɹɪm.

The mound covered a good two hides, but the grassy slope rose at an easy slant. The gray spire reared into the sky, squared and broad enough despite its height to seem massive, almost squat. Rand's laughter died, and he pulled Red up, his face grim.

"ɪz ðət hɔkwɪŋz mɑnjəmənt, lɔɹd ɹænd?" hʊɹɪn æskt ənizəli. "ɪt dʌzn lʊk ɹaɪt, sʌmhaʊ."

"Is that Hawkwing's monument, Lord Rand?" Hurin asked uneasily. "It doesn't look right, somehow."

ɹænd ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə hɑɹʃ, æŋɡjəlɝ skɹɪp ðət kʌvɝd ðə feɪs ə ðə mɑnjəmənt, ən i ɹɛkəɡnaɪz səm ə ðə sɪmbəlz tʃɪzəld ɑn ðə bɹɛdθ, tʃɪzəld əz tɔl əz ə mæn. ðə hɔɹn skʌl ə ðə dɑvɑl tʃɹɑləks. ði aɪɝn fɪst ə ðə deɪmən. ðə tʃɹaɪɾənt ə ðə koʊbəl, ən ðə wɝlwɪn ə ði ɑfɹeɪt. ðəɹ wɑz ə hɔk, tu, kɑɹv nɪɹ ðə bɑɾəm. wɪð ə wɪŋspæn ə tɛn peɪsɪz, ɪt leɪ ɑn ɪts bæk, pɪɹs baɪ ə laɪtnɪŋ boʊlt, ən ɹeɪvənz pɛkt əɾ ɪts aɪz. ðə hjudʒ wɪŋz ətɑp ðə spaɪɹ sim tə blɑk ðə sʌn.

Rand recognized the harsh, angular script that covered the face of the monument, and he recognized some of the symbols chiseled on the breadth, chiseled as tall as a man. The horned skull of the Dha'vol Trollocs. The iron fist of the Dhai'mon. The trident of the Ko'bal, and the whirlwind of the Ahf'frait. There was a hawk, too, carved near the bottom. With a wingspan of ten paces, it lay on its back, pierced by a lightning bolt, and ravens pecked at its eyes. The huge wings atop the spire seemed to block the sun.

hi hɝd lɔɪəl ɡæləpɪŋ ʌp bɪhaɪn hɪm.

He heard Loial galloping up behind him.

"aɪ tʃɹaɪd tə tɛl ju, ɹænd," lɔɪəl sɛd. "ɪɾ ɪz ə ɹeɪvən, nɑɾ ə hɔk. aɪ kəd si ɪt klɪɹli." hʊɹɪn tɝn ɪz hɔɹs, ɹəfjuzɪŋ ivən tə lʊk ət ðə spaɪɹ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ.

"I tried to tell you, Rand," Loial said. "It is a raven, not a hawk. I could see it clearly." Hurin turned his horse, refusing even to look at the spire any longer.

"bʌt haʊ?" ɹænd sɛd. "ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ wʌn ə vɪktɝi oʊvɝ ðə tʃɹɑləks hɪɹ. ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd soʊ."

"But how?" Rand said. "Artur Hawkwing won a victory over the Trollocs here. Ingtar said so."

"nɑt hɪɹ," lɔɪəl sɛd sloʊli. "ɑbviəsli nɑt hɪɹ. 'fɹʌm stoʊn tə stoʊn ɹʌn ðə laɪnz ʌv ɪt, bɪtwin ðə wɝlz ðət maɪt bi.' aɪv bɪn θɪŋkɪŋ ɑn ɪt, ən aɪ bɪliv aɪ noʊ wʌt 'ðə wɝlz ðət maɪt bi' ɑɹ. meɪbi aɪ du. wɝlz əɹ wɝl maɪɾ əv bɪn ɪf θɪŋz hæd hæpən dɪfɹənli. meɪbi ðæts waɪ ɪts ɔl soʊ . . . wɑʃt-aʊt lʊkɪŋ. kəz ɪts ən 'ɪf,' ə 'meɪbi.' dʒʌst ə ʃædoʊ ʌv ðə ɹil wɝld. ɪn ðɪs wɝld, aɪ θɪŋk, ðə tʃɹɑləks wʌn. meɪbi ðæts waɪ wɪv nɑt sin ɛni vɪlədʒəz əɹ pipəl."

"Not here," Loial said slowly. "Obviously not here. 'From Stone to Stone run the lines of it, between the worlds that might be.' I've been thinking on it, and I believe I know what 'the worlds that might be' are. Maybe I do. Worlds our world might have been if things had happened differently. Maybe that's why it is all so . . . washed-out looking. Because it's an 'if,' a 'maybe.' Just a shadow of the real world. In this world, I think, the Trollocs won. Maybe that's why we have not seen any villages or people."

ɹændz skɪn kɹɔld. wɛɹ tʃɹɑləks wʌn, ðeɪ dɪd nɑt liv hjumənz əlaɪv ɪksɛp fəɹ fud. ɪf ðeɪ hæd wʌn əkɹɔs ən ɪntaɪɝ wɝld. . . . "ɪf ðə tʃɹɑləks hæd wʌn, ðeɪ wəd bi ɛvɹiwɛɹ. wiɾ əv sin ə θaʊzən ə ðɛm baɪ naʊ. wid bi dɛd sɪns jɛstɝdeɪ."

Rand's skin crawled. Where Trollocs won, they did not leave humans alive except for food. If they had won across an entire world. . . . "If the Trollocs had won, they would be everywhere. We'd have seen a thousand of them by now. We'd be dead since yesterday."

"aɪ də nɑt noʊ, ɹænd. pɝhæps, æftɝ ðeɪ kɪl ðə pipəl, ðeɪ kɪld wʌn ənʌðɝ. tʃɹɑləks lɪv tə kɪl. ðəɾ ɪz ɔl ðeɪ du; ðəɾ ɪz ɔl ðeɪ ɑɹ. aɪ dʒʌs doʊnt noʊ."

"I do not know, Rand. Perhaps, after they killed the people, they killed one another. Trollocs live to kill. That is all they do; that is all they are. I just don't know."

"lɔɹd ɹænd," hʊɹɪn sɛɾ əbɹʌpli, "sʌmθɪŋ muv daʊn ðɛɹ."

"Lord Rand," Hurin said abruptly, "something moved down there."

ɹænd wɝld ɪz hɔɹs, ɹɛɾi tə si tʃɑɹdʒɪŋ tʃɹɑləks, bʌt hʊɹɪn wɑz pɔɪntɪŋ bæk ðə weɪ ðeɪ hæd kʌm, ət nʌθɪŋ. "wʌt dɪd jə si, hʊɹɪn? wɛɹ?"

Rand whirled his horse, ready to see charging Trollocs, but Hurin was pointing back the way they had come, at nothing. "What did you see, Hurin? Where?"

ðə snɪfɝ lɛɾ ɪz ɑɹm dʒɹɑp. "ɹaɪɾ ət ði ɛdʒ ə ðət klʌmp ə tʃɹiz ðɛɹ, əbaʊɾ ə maɪl. aɪ θɔɾ ɪt wɑz . . . ə wʊmən . . . ən sʌmθɪŋ ɛls aɪ kʊdn meɪk aʊt, bʌt. . . ." hi ʃɪvɝd. "ɪts soʊ hɑɹd tə meɪk aʊt θɪŋz ðəɾ ɑɹən ʌndɝ jəɹ noʊz. ɑ, ðɪs pleɪs əz maɪ ɡʌts ɔl ɔwɝl. aɪm laɪkli ɪmædʒənɪŋ θɪŋz, maɪ lɔɹd. ðɪs ɪz ə pleɪs fəɹ kwɪɹ fænsiz." hɪz ʃoʊldɝz hʌntʃt əz ɪf i fɛl ðə spaɪɹ pɹɛsɪŋ ɑn ðɛm. "noʊ daʊɾ ɪt wɑz dʒʌs ðə wɪnd, maɪ lɔɹd."

The sniffer let his arm drop. "Right at the edge of that clump of trees there, about a mile. I thought it was . . . a woman . . . and something else I couldn't make out, but. . . ." He shivered. "It's so hard to make out things that aren't under your nose. Aaah, this place has my guts all awhirl. I'm likely imagining things, my Lord. This is a place for queer fancies." His shoulders hunched as if he felt the spire pressing on them. "No doubt it was just the wind, my Lord."

lɔɪəl sɛd, "ðɛɹz sʌmθɪŋ ɛls tə kənsɪɾɝ, aɪm əfɹeɪd." hi saʊndəd tʃɹʌbəld əɡɛn. hi pɔɪntəd saʊθwɝd. "wʌt dʒju si ɔf ðɛɹ?"

Loial said, "There's something else to consider, I'm afraid." He sounded troubled again. He pointed southward. "What do you see off there?"

ɹænd skwɪntɪɾ əɡɛns ðə weɪ θɪŋz fɑɹ ɔf sim tə slaɪd təwɔɹd hɪm. "læn laɪk wʌt wiv bɪn kɹɔsɪŋ. tʃɹiz. ðən səm hɪlz, ən maʊntənz. nʌθɪŋ ɛls. wʌt dʒju wɑn mi tə si?"

Rand squinted against the way things far off seemed to slide toward him. "Land like what we've been crossing. Trees. Then some hills, and mountains. Nothing else. What do you want me to see?"

"ðə maʊntənz," lɔɪəl saɪd. ðə tʌfs ɑn ɪz ɪɹz dʒɹupt, ən ði ɛnz ə hɪz aɪbɹaʊz wɝ daʊn ɑn ɪz tʃiks. "ðæɾ əz tə bi kɪnsleɪɝz dæɡɝ, ɹænd. ðəɹ ɑɹən ɛni ʌðɝ maʊntənz ðeɪ kəd bi, ənlɛs ðɪs wɝld ɪz kəmplitli dɪfɹən fɹəm aʊɝz. bʌt kɪnsleɪɝz dæɡɝ laɪz mɔɹ ðən ə hʌnʒɹəd liɡz saʊθ ə ði ɛɹɪnɪn. ə ɡʊd bɪt mɔɹ. dɪstənsəz ɑɹ hɑɹd tə dʒʌdʒ ɪn ðɪs pleɪs, bʌt. . . . aɪ θɪŋk wɪl ɹitʃ əm bɪfɔɹ dɑɹk." hi dɪd nɑɾ əv tə seɪ ɛni mɔɹ. ðeɪ kəd nɑɾ əv kʌvɝɾ oʊvɝ ə hʌnʒɹəd liɡz ɪn lɛs ðən θɹi deɪz.

"The mountains," Loial sighed. The tufts on his ears drooped, and the ends of his eyebrows were down on his cheeks. "That has to be Kinslayer's Dagger, Rand. There aren't any other mountains they could be, unless this world is completely different from ours. But Kinslayer's Dagger lies more than a hundred leagues south of the Erinin. A good bit more. Distances are hard to judge in this place, but. . . . I think we will reach them before dark." He did not have to say any more. They could not have covered over a hundred leagues in less than three days.

wɪθaʊt θɪŋkɪŋ, ɹænd mʌɾɝd, "meɪbi ðɪs pleɪs ɪz laɪk ðə weɪz." hi hɝd hʊɹɪn moʊn, ən ɪnstənli ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪd nɑt kipɪŋ ə ɹeɪn ɑn ɪz tʌŋ.

Without thinking, Rand muttered, "Maybe this place is like the Ways." He heard Hurin moan, and instantly regretted not keeping a rein on his tongue.

ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə plɛzən θɔt. ɛntɝ ə weɪɡeɪt - ðeɪ kəd bi faʊn dʒʌst aʊtsaɪɾ oʊɡiɝ stɛɾɪŋ, ən ɪn oʊɡiɝ ɡɹoʊvz - ɛntɝ ən wɔk fəɹ ə deɪ, ən jə kəd liv baɪ ənʌðɝ weɪɡeɪɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd liɡz fɹəm wɛɹ jə stɑɹɾəd. ðə weɪz wɝ dɑɹk, naʊ, ən faʊl, ən tə tʃɹævəl əm mɛn tə ɹɪsk dɛθ əɹ mædnəs. ivən feɪdz fɪɹd tə tʃɹævəl ðə weɪz.

It was not a pleasant thought. Enter a Waygate - they could be found just outside Ogier stedding, and in Ogier groves - enter and walk for a day, and you could leave by another Waygate a hundred leagues from where you started. The Ways were dark, now, and foul, and to travel them meant to risk death or madness. Even Fades feared to travel the Ways.

"ɪf ɪɾ ɪz, ɹænd," lɔɪəl sɛd sloʊli, "kæn ə mɪsstɛp kɪl əs hɪɹ, tu? ɑɹ ðəɹ θɪŋz wɪv nɑt jɛt sin ðət kən də wɝs ðən kɪl ʌs?" hʊɹɪn moʊn əɡɛn.

"If it is, Rand," Loial said slowly, "can a misstep kill us here, too? Are there things we have not yet seen that can do worse than kill us?" Hurin moaned again.

ðeɪ hæd bɪn dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ ðə wɔɾɝ, ɹaɪɾɪŋ əlɔŋ əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd nɑɾ ə kənsɝn ɪn ðə wɝld. ʌnkənsɝn wəd kɪl kwɪkli ɪn ðə weɪz. ɹænd swɑloʊd, hoʊpɪŋ ɪz stʌmək wəd sɛɾəl.

They had been drinking the water, riding along as if they had not a concern in the world. Unconcern would kill quickly in the Ways. Rand swallowed, hoping his stomach would settle.

"ɪɾ ɪz tu leɪt fəɹ wɝiɪŋ əbaʊt wʌɾ ɪz pæst," hi sɛd. "fɹʌm hɪɹ ɑn, ðoʊ, wɪl wɑtʃ əɹ stɛp." hi ɡlænst ət hʊɹɪn. ðə snɪfɝz hɛd hæd sʌŋk bɪtwin ɪz ʃoʊldɝz, ən ɪz aɪz dɑɹɾɪd əz ɪf i wʌndɝd wʌt wəd lip ət hɪm, ən fɹəm wɛɹ. ðə mæn hæd ɹʌn daʊn mɝɾɝɝz, bʌt ðɪs wɑz mɔɹ ðən i hæɾ ɛvɝ bɑɹɡən fɔɹ. "hoʊld ɑn tə jɝsɛlf, hʊɹɪn. wəɹ nɑt dɛd, jɛt, ən wi woʊn bi. wɪl dʒʌst əv tə bi kɛɹfəl fɹəm hɪɹ ɑn. ðæts ɔl."

"It is too late for worrying about what is past," he said. "From here on, though, we will watch our step." He glanced at Hurin. The sniffer's head had sunk between his shoulders, and his eyes darted as if he wondered what would leap at him, and from where. The man had run down murderers, but this was more than he had ever bargained for. "Hold on to yourself, Hurin. We are not dead, yet, and we won't be. We will just have to be careful from here on. That's all."

ɪt wɑz ət ðət moʊmən ðeɪ hɝd ðə skɹim, θɪn wɪð dɪstəns.

It was at that moment they heard the scream, thin with distance.

"ə wʊmən!" hʊɹɪn sɛd. ivən ðɪs mʌtʃ ðət wɑz nɔɹməl sim tə ɹaʊs ɪm ə lɪɾəl. "aɪ nu aɪ sɔ - "

"A woman!" Hurin said. Even this much that was normal seemed to rouse him a little. "I knew I saw - "

ənʌðɝ skɹim keɪm, mɔɹ dɛspɹɪt ðən ðə fɝst.

Another scream came, more desperate than the first.

"nɑɾ ənlɛs ʃi kən flaɪ," ɹænd sɛd. "ʃiz saʊθ ʌv ʌs." hi kɪkt ɹɛd tə ə dɛd ɹʌn ɪn tu stʃɹaɪdz.

"Not unless she can fly," Rand said. "She's south of us." He kicked Red to a dead run in two strides.

"bi kɛɹfəl jə sɛd!" lɔɪəl ʃaʊɾəd æftɝ hɪm. "laɪt, ɹænd, ɹɪmɛmbɝ! bi kɛɹfəl!"

"Be careful you said!" Loial shouted after him. "Light, Rand, remember! Be careful!"

ɹænd leɪ loʊ ɑn ɹɛdz bæk, lɛɾɪŋ ðə stæljən ɹʌn. ðə skɹimz dʒɹu hɪm ɑn. ɪt wɑz izi tə seɪ bi kɛɹfəl, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz tɛɹɝ ɪn ðət wʊmənz vɔɪs. ʃi dɪd nɑt saʊn əz ɪf ʃi hæd taɪm fəɹ ɪm tə bi kɛɹfəl. ɑn ði ɛdʒ ʌv ənʌðɝ stʃɹim, ɪn ə ʃɪɹ-bæŋk tʃænəl dipɝ ðən moʊst, hi dʒɹu ɹeɪn; ɹɛd skɪɾəd ɪn ə ʃaʊɝ ə stoʊnz ən dɝt. ðə skɹimz wɝ kʌmɪŋ. . . . ðɛɹ!

Rand lay low on Red's back, letting the stallion run. The screams drew him on. It was easy to say be careful, but there was terror in that woman's voice. She did not sound as if she had time for him to be careful. On the edge of another stream, in a sheer-banked channel deeper than most, he drew rein; Red skidded in a shower of stones and dirt. The screams were coming. . . . There!

hi tʊk ɪɾ ɔl ɪn əɾ ə ɡlæns. pɝhæps tu hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz əweɪ, ðə wʊmən stʊd bɪsaɪɾ əɹ hɔɹs ɪn ðə stʃɹim, boʊθ ə ðɛm bækt əɡɛns ðə fɑɹ bæŋk. wɪð ə bɹoʊkən lɛŋθ ə bɹæntʃ, ʃi wɑz fɛndɪŋ ɔf ə snɑɹlɪŋ . . . sʌmθɪŋ. ɹænd swɑloʊd, stʌn fəɹ ə moʊmənt. ɪf ə fɹɑɡ wɝ əz bɪɡ əz ə bɛɹ, əɹ ɪf ə bɛɹ hæɾ ə fɹɑɡz ɡɹeɪ-ɡɹin haɪd, ɪt maɪt lʊk laɪk ðæt. ə bɪɡ bɛɹ.

He took it all in at a glance. Perhaps two hundred paces away, the woman stood beside her horse in the stream, both of them backed against the far bank. With a broken length of branch, she was fending off a snarling . . . something. Rand swallowed, stunned for a moment. If a frog were as big as a bear, or if a bear had a frog's gray-green hide, it might look like that. A big bear.

nɑt lɛɾɪŋ hɪmsɛlf θɪŋk əbaʊt ðə kɹitʃɝ, hi lɛp tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ənlɪmbɝɪŋ ɪz baʊ. ɪf i tʊk ðə taɪm tə ɹaɪd kloʊsɝ, ɪt maɪt bi tu leɪt. ðə wʊmən wɑz bɛɹli kipɪŋ ðə . . . θɪŋ . . . ət ði ɛdʒ ə ðə bɹæntʃ. ɪt wɑz ə fɛɹ dɪstəns - hi kɛp blɪŋkɪŋ əz i tʃɹaɪd tə dʒʌdʒ ɪt; ðə dɪstəns sim tə tʃeɪnʒ baɪ spænz ɛvɹi taɪm ðə θɪŋ muvd - jɛɾ ə bɪɡ tɑɹɡət. hɪz bændədʒ hæn meɪd dʒɹɔɪŋ ɑkwɝd, bʌɾ i hæɾ ən æɹoʊ lust ɔlmoʊs bɪfɔɹ ɪz fit wɝ sɛt.

Not letting himself think about the creature, he leaped to the ground, unlimbering his bow. If he took the time to ride closer, it might be too late. The woman was barely keeping the . . . thing . . . at the edge of the branch. It was a fair distance - he kept blinking as he tried to judge it; the distance seemed to change by spans every time the thing moved - yet a big target. His bandaged hand made drawing awkward, but he had an arrow loosed almost before his feet were set.

ðə ʃæf sæŋk ɪndə ðə lɛðɝi haɪd fəɹ hæf ɪts lɛŋθ, ən ðə kɹitʃɝ spʌn tə feɪs ɹænd. ɹænd tʊk ə stɛp bæk dɪspaɪt ðə dɪstəns. ðət hjudʒ, wɛdʒ-ʃeɪp hɛd hæd nɛvɝ bɪn ɑn ɛni ænəməl i kəɾ ɪmædʒən, nɔɹ ðət waɪd, hɔɹni-lɪp bik ʌv ə maʊθ, hʊk fəɹ ɹɪpɪŋ flɛʃ. ən ɪt hæd θɹi aɪz, smɔl, ən fɪɹs, ən ɹɪŋ baɪ hɑɹd-lʊkɪŋ ɹɪdʒəz. ɡæðɝɪŋ ɪtsɛlf, ðə θɪŋ baʊndəd təwɔɹɾ ɪm daʊn ðə stʃɹim ɪn ɡɹeɪt, splæʃɪŋ lips. tə ɹændz aɪ, səm ə ðə lips sim tə kʌvɝ twaɪs əz mʌtʃ dɪstəns əz ʌðɝz, ðoʊ hi wɑz ʃʊɹ ðeɪ wɝ ɔl ðə seɪm.

The shaft sank into the leathery hide for half its length, and the creature spun to face Rand. Rand took a step back despite the distance. That huge, wedge-shaped head had never been on any animal he could imagine, nor that wide, horny-lipped beak of a mouth, hooked for ripping flesh. And it had three eyes, small, and fierce, and ringed by hard-looking ridges. Gathering itself, the thing bounded toward him down the stream in great, splashing leaps. To Rand's eye, some of the leaps seemed to cover twice as much distance as others, though he was sure they were all the same.

"æn aɪ," ðə wʊmən kɔld. ʃi saʊndəd sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli kɑm, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ əɹ skɹimz. "ju mʌs hɪɾ ən aɪ tə kɪl ɪt."

"An eye," the woman called. She sounded surprisingly calm, considering her screams. "You must hit an eye to kill it."

hi dʒɹu ðə flɛtʃɪŋ ʌv ənʌðɝ æɹoʊ bæk tə hɪz ɪɹ. ɹɪlʌktənli, hi sɔt ðə vɔɪd; hi dɪd nɑt wɑn tə, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz fəɹ ðɪs ðət tæm hæd tɔt hɪm, ən i nu hi kəd nɛvɝ meɪk ðə ʃɑt wɪθaʊɾ ɪt. maɪ fɑðɝ, hi θɔt wɪð ə sɛns ə lɔs, ən ɛmptinəs fɪl hɪm. ðə kweɪvɝɪŋ laɪɾ ə seɪɾɪn wɑz ðɛɹ, bʌɾ i ʃʌɾ ɪɾ əweɪ. hi wɑz wʌn wɪð ðə baʊ, wɪð ði æɹoʊ, wɪð ðə mɑnstʃɹəs ʃeɪp lipɪŋ təwɔɹd hɪm. wʌn wɪð ðə taɪni aɪ. hi dɪd nɑɾ ivən fil ði æɹoʊ liv ðə bɑstʃɹɪŋ.

He drew the fletching of another arrow back to his ear. Reluctantly, he sought the void; he did not want to, but it was for this that Tam had taught him, and he knew he could never make the shot without it. My father, he thought with a sense of loss, and emptiness filled him. The quavering light of saidin was there, but he shut it away. He was one with the bow, with the arrow, with the monstrous shape leaping toward him. One with the tiny eye. He did not even feel the arrow leave the bowstring.

ðə kɹitʃɝ ɹoʊz ɪn ənʌðɝ baʊnd, ən ət ðə pik, ði æɹoʊ stʃɹʌk ɪts sɛntʃɹəl aɪ. ðə θɪŋ lændəd, faʊnteɪnɪŋ ənʌðɝ hjudʒ splæʃ ʌv wɔɾɝ ən mʌd. ɹɪpəlz spɹɛɾ aʊt fɹəm ɪt, bʌɾ ɪt dɪd nɑt muv.

The creature rose in another bound, and at the peak, the arrow struck its central eye. The thing landed, fountaining another huge splash of water and mud. Ripples spread out from it, but it did not move.

"wɛl ʃɑt, ən bɹeɪvli," ðə wʊmən kɔld. ʃi wɑz ɑn əɹ hɔɹs, ɹaɪɾɪŋ tə mit hɪm. ɹænd fɛl veɪɡli sɝpɹaɪz ðət ʃi hæd nɑt ɹʌn wʌns ðə θɪŋz ətɛnʃən wɑz daɪvɝɾɪd. ʃi ɹoʊd pæs ðə bʌlk, stɪl sɝaʊndəd baɪ ðə ɹɪpəlz ʌv ɪts daɪɪŋ, wɪθaʊɾ ivən ə daʊnwɝd ɡlæns, skɹæmbəld əɹ hɔɹs ʌp ðə bæŋk ən dɪsmaʊntɪd. "fju mɛn wəd stæn tə feɪs ðə tʃɑɹdʒ ʌv ə ɡɹoʊm, maɪ lɔɹd."

"Well shot, and bravely," the woman called. She was on her horse, riding to meet him. Rand felt vaguely surprised that she had not run once the thing's attention was diverted. She rode past the bulk, still surrounded by the ripples of its dying, without even a downward glance, scrambled her horse up the bank and dismounted. "Few men would stand to face the charge of a grolm, my Lord."

ʃi wɑz ɔl ɪn waɪt, hɝ dʒɹɛs dɪvaɪɾəd fəɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ ən bɛltəɾ ɪn sɪlvɝ, ən əɹ buts, pikɪŋ aʊt fɹəm ʌndɝ əɹ hɛmz, wɝ tuld ɪn sɪlvɝ, tu. ivən əɹ sæɾəl wɑz waɪt, ən sɪlvɝ-maʊntəd. hɝ snoʊi mɛɹ, wɪð ɪts ɑɹtʃt nɛk ən deɪnti stɛp, wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz tɔl əz ɹændz beɪ. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðə wʊmən hɝsɛlf - ʃi wɑz pɝhæps nɪneɪivz eɪdʒ, hi θɔt - hu hɛld ɪz aɪz. ʃi wɑz tɔl, fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ; ə hæn tɔlɝ ən ʃi kəɾ ɔlmoʊs lʊk ɪm ɪn ði aɪz. fəɹ ənʌðɝ, ʃi wɑz bjuɾəfəl, aɪvɝi-peɪl skɪn kəntʃɹæstɪŋ ʃɑɹpli wɪð lɔŋ, naɪt-dɑɹk hɛɹ ən blæk aɪz. hi hæd sin bjuɾəfəl wɪmən. mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz bjuɾəfəl, ɪf kul, ən soʊ wɑz nɪneɪiv, wən əɹ tɛmpɝ dɪd nɑt ɡɛt ðə bɛɾɝ ə hɝ. ɛɡwin, ən ɪleɪn, ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ʌv ændɝ, wɝ itʃ ɪnʌf tə teɪk ə mænz bɹɛθ. bʌt ðɪs wʊmən. . . . hɪz tʌŋ stʌk tə ðə ɹuf ə hɪz maʊθ; hi fɛlt ɪz hɑɹt stɑɹt biɾɪŋ əɡɛn.

She was all in white, her dress divided for riding and belted in silver, and her boots, peeking out from under her hems, were tooled in silver, too. Even her saddle was white, and silver-mounted. Her snowy mare, with its arched neck and dainty step, was almost as tall as Rand's bay. But it was the woman herself - she was perhaps Nynaeve's age, he thought - who held his eyes. She was tall, for one thing; a hand taller and she could almost look him in the eyes. For another, she was beautiful, ivory-pale skin contrasting sharply with long, night-dark hair and black eyes. He had seen beautiful women. Moiraine was beautiful, if cool, and so was Nynaeve, when her temper did not get the better of her. Egwene, and Elayne, the Daughter-Heir of Andor, were each enough to take a man's breath. But this woman. . . . His tongue stuck to the roof of his mouth; he felt his heart start beating again.

"jɔɹ ɹɪteɪnɝz, maɪ lɔɹd?"

"Your retainers, my Lord?"

stɑɹɾəld, hi lʊkt ɝaʊnd. hʊɹɪn ən lɔɪəl hæd dʒɔɪn ðɛm. hʊɹɪn wɑz stɛɹɪŋ ðə weɪ ɹænd nu hi hæd bɪn, ən ivən ði oʊɡiɝ sim fæsəneɪɾəd. "maɪ fɹɛnz," hi sɛd. "lɔɪəl, ən hʊɹɪn. maɪ neɪm ɪz ɹænd. ɹænd ælθɹ."

Startled, he looked around. Hurin and Loial had joined them. Hurin was staring the way Rand knew he had been, and even the Ogier seemed fascinated. "My friends," he said. "Loial, and Hurin. My name is Rand. Rand al'Thor."

"aɪ hæv nɛvɝ θɔɾ ʌv ɪt bɪfɔɹ," lɔɪəl sɛɾ əbɹʌpli, saʊndɪŋ əz ɪf i wɝ tɔkɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf; "bʌɾ ɪf ðəɹ ɪz sətʃ ə θɪŋ əz pɝfək hjumən bjuɾi, ɪn feɪs ən fɔɹm, ðən jə - "

"I have never thought of it before," Loial said abruptly, sounding as if he were talking to himself; "but if there is such a thing as perfect human beauty, in face and form, then you - "

"lɔɪəl!" ɹænd ʃaʊɾəd. ði oʊɡiɝz ɪɹz stɪfən ɪn ɪmbɛɹəsmənt. ɹændz oʊn ɪɹz wɝ ɹɛd; lɔɪəlz wɝdz hæd bɪn tu kloʊs tə wʌɾ i hɪmsɛlf wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ.

"Loial!" Rand shouted. The Ogier's ears stiffened in embarrassment. Rand's own ears were red; Loial's words had been too close to what he himself was thinking.

ðə wʊmən læf mjuzɪkli, bʌt ðə nɛkst ɪnstənt ʃi wɑz ɔl ɹiɡəl fɔɹmæləɾi, laɪk ə kwin ɑn əɹ θɹoʊn. "aɪ æm kɔl səlin," ʃi sɛd. "ju hæv ɹɪsk jəɹ laɪf, ən seɪv maɪn. aɪm jʊɹz, lɔɹd ɹænd ælθɹ." ænd, tə ɹændz hɔɹɝ, ʃi nɛl bɪfɔɹ hɪm.

The woman laughed musically, but the next instant she was all regal formality, like a queen on her throne. "I am called Selene," she said. "You have risked your life, and saved mine. I am yours, Lord Rand al'Thor." And, to Rand's horror, she knelt before him.

nɑt lʊkɪŋ ət hʊɹɪn əɹ lɔɪəl, hi heɪstəli pʊld əɹ tə hɝ fit. "ə mæn u wɪl nɑt daɪ tə seɪv ə wʊmən ɪz noʊ mæn." ɪmiɾiətli hi dɪsɡɹeɪs hɪmsɛlf baɪ blʌʃɪŋ. ɪt wɑz ə ʃaɪnɝən seɪɪŋ, ən i nu ɪt saʊndəd pɑmpəs bɪfɔɹ ɪt wɑz aʊɾ ə hɪz maʊθ, bʌɾ əɹ mænɝ hæɾ ɪnfɛktəd hɪm, ən i kəd nɑt stɑp ɪt. "aɪ min. . . . ðəɾ ɪz, ɪt wɑz. . . ." ful, jə kæn tɛl ə wʊmən seɪvɪŋ əɹ laɪf wɑz nʌθɪŋ.
