"ɪt wɑz maɪ ɑnɝ." ðət saʊndəd veɪɡli ʃaɪnɝən ən fɔɹməl. hi hoʊpt ɪt wəd du; hɪz maɪnd wɑz əz blæŋk ʌv ɛniθɪŋ ɛls tə seɪ əz ɪf i wɝ stɪl ɪn ðə vɔɪd.

Not looking at Hurin or Loial, he hastily pulled her to her feet. "A man who will not die to save a woman is no man." Immediately he disgraced himself by blushing. It was a Shienaran saying, and he knew it sounded pompous before it was out of his mouth, but her manner had infected him, and he could not stop it. "I mean. . . . That is, it was. . . ." Fool, you can't tell a woman saving her life was nothing. "It was my honor." That sounded vaguely Shienaran and formal. He hoped it would do; his mind was as blank of anything else to say as if he were still in the void.

sʌɾənli hi bɪkeɪm kɑnʃəs ə hɝ aɪz ɑn hɪm. hɝ ɪkspɹɛʃən hæd nɑt tʃeɪnʒd, bʌɾ əɹ dɑɹk aɪz meɪɾ ɪm fil əz ɪf i wɝ neɪkəd. ənbɪddən, ðə θɔt keɪm ə səlin wɪð noʊ kloʊðz. hɪz feɪs wɛn ɹɛɾ əɡɛn. "ɑ! ɑ, wɛɹ ɑɹ jə fɹʌm, səlin? wɪv nɑt sin ənʌðɝ hjumən biɪŋ sɪns wi keɪm hɪɹ. ɪz jəɹ taʊn nɪɹbaɪ?" ʃi lʊkt əɾ ɪm θɔtfəli, ən i stɛp bæk. hɝ lʊk meɪɾ ɪm tu əwɛɹ ə haʊ kloʊs tə hɝ i wɑz.

Suddenly he became conscious of her eyes on him. Her expression had not changed, but her dark eyes made him feel as if he were naked. Unbidden, the thought came of Selene with no clothes. His face went red again. "Aaah! Ah, where are you from, Selene? We have not seen another human being since we came here. Is your town nearby?" She looked at him thoughtfully, and he stepped back. Her look made him too aware of how close to her he was.

"aɪm nɑt fɹəm ðɪs wɝld, maɪ lɔɹd," ʃi sɛd. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ noʊ pipəl hɪɹ. nʌθɪŋ lɪvɪŋ ɪksɛp ðə ɡɹoʊm ən ə fju ʌðɝ kɹitʃɝz laɪk ðɛm. aɪm fɹəm kɛɹhin. ən əz tə haʊ aɪ keɪm hɪɹ, aɪ doʊnt noʊ, ɪɡzækli. aɪ wɑz aʊt ɹaɪɾɪŋ, ən aɪ stɑp tə næp, ən wən aɪ woʊk, maɪ hɔɹs ən aɪ wɝ hɪɹ. aɪ kən oʊnli hoʊp, maɪ lɔɹd, ðət jə kən seɪv mi əɡɛn, ən hɛlp mi ɡoʊ hoʊm."

"I'm not from this world, my Lord," she said. "There are no people here. Nothing living except the grolm and a few other creatures like them. I am from Cairhien. And as to how I came here, I don't know, exactly. I was out riding, and I stopped to nap, and when I woke, my horse and I were here. I can only hope, my Lord, that you can save me again, and help me go home."

"səlin, aɪm nɑɾ ə . . . ðəɾ ɪz, pliz kɔl mi ɹænd." hɪz ɪɹz fɛl hɑɾ əɡɛn. laɪt, ɪt woʊn hɝɾ ɛniθɪŋ ɪf ʃi θɪŋks ɪm ə lɔɹd. bɝn mi, ɪt woʊn hɝɾ ɛniθɪŋ.

"Selene, I am not a . . . that is, please call me Rand." His ears felt hot again. Light, it won't hurt anything if she thinks I'm a lord. Burn me, it won't hurt anything.

"ɪf jə wɪʃ ɪt . . . ɹænd." hɝ smaɪl meɪɾ ɪz θɹoʊt taɪɾən. "ju wɪl hɛlp mi?"

"If you wish it . . . Rand." Her smile made his throat tighten. "You will help me?"

"ʌv kɔɹs, aɪ wɪl." bɝn mi, bʌt ʃiz bjuɾəfəl. ən lʊkɪŋ ət mi laɪk ɪm ə hɪɹoʊ ɪn ə stɔɹi. hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd tə klɪɹ ɪɾ ə fulɪʃnəs. "bʌt fɝst wɪv tə faɪn ðə mɛn wəɹ fɑloʊɪŋ. əl tʃɹaɪ tə kip jə aʊɾ ə deɪnʒɝ, bʌt wi mʌs faɪn ðɛm. kʌmɪŋ wɪð əs wɪl bi bɛɾɝ ðən steɪɪŋ hɪɹ əloʊn."

"Of course, I will." Burn me, but she's beautiful. And looking at me like I'm a hero in a story. He shook his head to clear it of foolishness. "But first we have to find the men we are following. I'll try to keep you out of danger, but we must find them. Coming with us will be better than staying here alone."

fəɹ ə moʊmənt ʃi wɑz saɪlənt, hɝ feɪs blæŋk ən smuð; ɹænd hæd noʊ aɪdiə wʌt ʃi wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ, ɪksɛp ðət ʃi sim tə bi stʌɾiɪŋ ɪm ənu. "ə mæn ə duɾi," ʃi sɛd faɪnəli. ə smɔl smaɪl tʌtʃt əɹ lɪps. "aɪ laɪk ðæt. jɛs. hu ɑɹ ðiz mɪskɹiəns jə fɑloʊ?"

For a moment she was silent, her face blank and smooth; Rand had no idea what she was thinking, except that she seemed to be studying him anew. "A man of duty," she said finally. A small smile touched her lips. "I like that. Yes. Who are these miscreants you follow?"

"dɑɹkfɹɛnz ən tʃɹɑləks, maɪ leɪɾi," hʊɹɪn bɝst aʊt. hi meɪɾ ən ɑkwɝd baʊ tə hɝ fɹəm ɪz sæɾəl. "ðeɪ dɪd mɝɾɝ ɪn fæl dæɹə kip ən stoʊl ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ, maɪ leɪɾi, bʌt lɔɹd ɹænd wɪl fɛtʃ ɪt bæk."

"Darkfriends and Trollocs, my Lady," Hurin burst out. He made an awkward bow to her from his saddle. "They did murder in Fal Dara keep and stole the Horn of Valere, my Lady, but Lord Rand will fetch it back."

ɹænd stɛɹɾ ət ðə snɪfɝ ɹufəli; hʊɹɪn ɡeɪv ə wik ɡɹɪn. soʊ mʌtʃ fəɹ sikɹəsi. ɪt dɪd nɑt mæɾɝ hɪɹ, hi səpoʊzd, bʌt wʌns bæk ɪn ðɛɹ wɝld. . . . "səlin, jə mʌs nɑt seɪ ɛniθɪŋ ə ðə hɔɹn tə ɛniwʌn. ɪf ɪt ɡɛts aʊt, wɪl əv ə hʌnʒɹəd pipəl ɑn əɹ hilz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡɛt ðə hɔɹn fəɹ ðɛmsɛlvz."

Rand stared at the sniffer ruefully; Hurin gave a weak grin. So much for secrecy. It did not matter here, he supposed, but once back in their world. . . . "Selene, you must not say anything of the Horn to anyone. If it gets out, we'll have a hundred people on our heels trying to get the Horn for themselves."

"noʊ, ɪt wəd nɛvɝ du," səlin sɛd, "fɔɹ ðət tə fɔl ɪndə ðə ɹɔŋ hænz. ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ. aɪ kəd nɑt tɛl jə haʊ ɔfən aɪv dʒɹimd ə tʌtʃɪŋ ɪt, hoʊldɪŋ ɪɾ ɪn maɪ hænz. jə mʌs pɹɑməs mi, wən juv ɪt, jəl lemi tʌtʃ ɪt."

"No, it would never do," Selene said, "for that to fall into the wrong hands. The Horn of Valere. I could not tell you how often I've dreamed of touching it, holding it in my hands. You must promise me, when you have it, you will let me touch it."

"bɪfɔɹ aɪ kən də ðæt, wɪv tə faɪn ɪt. wi hæd bɛɾɝ bi ɑn əɹ weɪ." ɹænd ɔfɝɾ ɪz hæn tə hɛlp əɹ maʊnt; hʊɹɪn skɹæmbəl daʊn tə hoʊld əɹ stɝəp. "wʌtɛvɝ ðət θɪŋ wɑz aɪ kɪld - ə ɡɹoʊm? - ðəɹ meɪ bi mɔɹ ə ðɛm ɝaʊnd." hɝ hænd wɑz fɝm - ðəɹ wɑz sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ stʃɹɛŋkθ ɪn əɹ ɡɹɪp - ən əɹ skɪn wɑz. . . . sɪlk? sʌmθɪŋ sɑftɝ, smuðɝ. ɹænd ʃɪvɝd.

"Before I can do that, we have to find it. We had better be on our way." Rand offered his hand to help her mount; Hurin scrambled down to hold her stirrup. "Whatever that thing was I killed - a grolm? - there may be more of them around." Her hand was firm - there was surprising strength in her grip - and her skin was. . . . Silk? Something softer, smoother. Rand shivered.

"ðɛɹ ɔlweɪz ɑɹ," səlin sɛd. ðə tɔl waɪt mɛɹ fɹɪskt ən bɛɹɾ əɹ tiθ wʌns ət ɹɛd, jɛt səlinz tʌtʃ ɑn ðə ɹeɪnz kwaɪəɾəd hɝ.

"There always are," Selene said. The tall white mare frisked and bared her teeth once at Red, yet Selene's touch on the reins quieted her.

ɹænd slʌŋ ɪz baʊ əkɹɔs ɪz bæk ən klaɪmd ɑntu ɹɛd. laɪt, haʊ kəɾ ɛniwʌnz skɪn bi soʊ sɑft? "hʊɹɪn, wɛɹz ðə tʃɹeɪl? hʊɹɪn? hʊɹɪn!"

Rand slung his bow across his back and climbed onto Red. Light, how could anyone's skin be so soft? "Hurin, where's the trail? Hurin? Hurin!"

ðə snɪfɝ ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt, ən lɛft ɔf stɛɹɪŋ ət səlin. "jɛs, lɔɹd ɹænd. ɑ . . . ðə tʃɹeɪl. saʊθ, maɪ lɔɹd. stɪl saʊθ."

The sniffer gave a start, and left off staring at Selene. "Yes, Lord Rand. Ah . . . the trail. South, my Lord. Still south."

"ðɛn lɛts ɹaɪd." ɹænd ɡeɪv ən ənizi lʊk ət ðə ɡɹeɪ-ɡɹin bʌlk ə ðə ɡɹoʊm laɪɪŋ ɪn ðə stʃɹim. ɪt hæd bɪn bɛɾɝ bɪlivɪŋ ðeɪ wɝ ði oʊnli lɪvɪŋ θɪŋz ɪn ðət wɝld. "teɪk ðə tʃɹeɪl, hʊɹɪn."

"Then let's ride." Rand gave an uneasy look at the gray-green bulk of the grolm lying in the stream. It had been better believing they were the only living things in that world. "Take the trail, Hurin."

səlin ɹoʊɾ əlɔŋsaɪd ɹænd ət fɝst, tɔkɪŋ ə ðɪs ən ðæt, æskɪŋ ɪm kwɛstʃənz ən kɔlɪŋ ɪm lɔɹd. hæf ə dʌzən taɪmz i stɑɹɾəd tə tɛl əɹ i wɑz noʊ lɔɹd, oʊnli ə ʃɛpɝd, ən ɛvɹi taɪm, lʊkɪŋ ət hɝ, hi kəd nɑt ɡɛt ðə wɝdz aʊt. ə leɪɾi laɪk əɹ wəd nɑt tɔk ðə seɪm weɪ wɪð ə ʃɛpɝd, hi wɑz ʃʊɹ, ivən wʌn u hæd seɪvd əɹ laɪf.

Selene rode alongside Rand at first, talking of this and that, asking him questions and calling him lord. Half a dozen times he started to tell her he was no lord, only a shepherd, and every time, looking at her, he could not get the words out. A lady like her would not talk the same way with a shepherd, he was sure, even one who had saved her life.

"ju wɪl bi ə ɡɹeɪt mæn wən juv faʊn ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ," ʃi toʊl hɪm. "ə mæn fəɹ ðə lɛdʒənz. ðə mæn u saʊnz ðə hɔɹn wɪl meɪk ɪz oʊn lɛdʒənz."

"You will be a great man when you've found the Horn of Valere," she told him. "A man for the legends. The man who sounds the Horn will make his own legends."

"aɪ doʊnt wɑnə saʊn ɪt, ən aɪ doʊnt wɑnə bi pɑɹɾ ʌv ɛni lɛdʒənd." hi dɪd nɑt noʊ ɪf ʃi wɑz wɛɹɪŋ pɝfjum, bʌt ðəɹ sim tə bi ə sɛn tə hɝ, sʌmθɪŋ ðət fɪld ɪz hɛd wɪð hɝ. spaɪsəz, ʃɑɹp ən swit, tɪklɪŋ ɪz noʊz, meɪkɪŋ ɪm swɑloʊ.

"I don't want to sound it, and I don't want to be part of any legend." He did not know if she was wearing perfume, but there seemed to be a scent to her, something that filled his head with her. Spices, sharp and sweet, tickling his nose, making him swallow.

"ɛvɹi mæn wɑns tə bi ɡɹeɪt. jə kəd bi ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst mæn ɪn ɔl ði eɪdʒəz."

"Every man wants to be great. You could be the greatest man in all the Ages."

ɪt saʊndəd tu kloʊs tə wʌt mɔɪɹeɪn hæd sɛd. ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wəd sɝɾənli stæn aʊt θɹu ði eɪdʒəz. "nɑt mi," hi sɛd fɝvənli. "aɪm dʒʌst" - hi θɔɾ ə hɝ skɔɹn ɪf i toʊld əɹ naʊ ðəɾ i wɑz oʊnli ə ʃɛpɝɾ æftɝ lɛɾɪŋ əɹ bɪliv i wɑz ə lɔɹd, ən tʃeɪnʒd wʌɾ i hæd bɪn gɑnə seɪ - "dʒʌs tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪn ɪt. ən tə hɛlp ə fɹɛnd."

It sounded too close to what Moiraine had said. The Dragon Reborn would certainly stand out through the Ages. "Not me," he said fervently. "I'm just" - he thought of her scorn if he told her now that he was only a shepherd after letting her believe he was a lord, and changed what he had been going to say - "just trying to find it. And to help a friend."

ʃi wɑz saɪlən ə moʊmənt, ðən sɛd, "juv hɝt jəɹ hænd."

She was silent a moment, then said, "You've hurt your hand."

"ɪɾ ɪz nʌθɪŋ." hi stɑɹɾəd tə pʊɾ ɪz ɪnʒɝd hæn ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz koʊt - ɪt θɹɑb fɹəm hoʊldɪŋ ðə ɹeɪnz - bʌt ʃi ɹitʃt aʊɾ ən tʊk ɪt.

"It is nothing." He started to put his injured hand inside his coat - it throbbed from holding the reins - but she reached out and took it.

hi wɑz soʊ sɝpɹaɪzd i lɛt hɝ, ən ðən ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə də ɪksɛpt iðɝ dʒɝk əweɪ ɹudli əɹ ɛls lɛɾ əɹ ənɹæp ðə kɝtʃəf. hɝ tʌtʃ fɛl kul ən ʃʊɹ. hɪz pɑm wɑz æŋɡɹəli ɹɛɾ ən pʌfi, bʌt ðə hɛɹən stɪl stʊɾ aʊt, pleɪnli ən klɪɹli.

He was so surprised he let her, and then there was nothing to do except either jerk away rudely or else let her unwrap the kerchief. Her touch felt cool and sure. His palm was angrily red and puffy, but the heron still stood out, plainly and clearly.

ʃi tʌtʃt ðə bɹænd wɪð ə fɪŋɡɝ, bʌt meɪd noʊ kɑmɛn ɑn ɪt, nɑɾ ivən tə æsk haʊ hi hæd kʌm baɪ ɪt. "ðɪs kəd stɪfən jəɹ hæn ɪf ɪts ʌntɛndəd. aɪ hæv ən ɔɪnmənt ðət ʃəd hɛlp." fɹəm ə pɑkəɾ ɪnsaɪɾ əɹ kloʊk ʃi pɹədust ə smɔl stoʊn vaɪəl, ənstɑpt ɪt, ən bɪɡæn dʒɛnli ɹʌbɪŋ ə waɪt sɑv ɑn ðə bɝn əz ðeɪ ɹoʊd.

She touched the brand with a finger, but made no comment on it, not even to ask how he had come by it. "This could stiffen your hand if it's untended. I have an ointment that should help." From a pocket inside her cloak she produced a small stone vial, unstopped it, and began gently rubbing a white salve on the burn as they rode.

ði ɔɪnmənt fɛl koʊld ət fɝst, ðən sim tə mɛlt əweɪ wɔɹmli ɪndə hɪz flɛʃ. ən ɪt wɝkt əz wɛl əz nɪneɪivz ɔɪnmənts səmtaɪmz dɪd. hi stɛɹɾ ɪn əmeɪzmən əz ðə ɹɛdnəs feɪɾəd ən ðə swɛlɪŋ wɛn daʊn ʌndɝ əɹ stʃɹoʊkɪŋ fɪŋɡɝz.

The ointment felt cold at first, then seemed to melt away warmly into his flesh. And it worked as well as Nynaeve's ointments sometimes did. He stared in amazement as the redness faded and the swelling went down under her stroking fingers.

"sʌm mɛn," ʃi sɛd, nɑt ɹeɪzɪŋ əɹ aɪz fɹəm ɪz hænd, "tʃuz tə sik ɡɹeɪtnəs, waɪl ʌðɝz ɑɹ fɔɹs tə ɪt. ɪts ɔlweɪz bɛɾɝ tə tʃuz ðən tə bi fɔɹst. ə mæn huz fɔɹst ɪz nɛvɝ kəmplitli hɪz oʊn mæstɝ. hi mʌs dæns ɑn ðə stʃɹɪŋz ə ðoʊz u fɔɹs hɪm."

"Some men," she said, not raising her eyes from his hand, "choose to seek greatness, while others are forced to it. It is always better to choose than to be forced. A man who's forced is never completely his own master. He must dance on the strings of those who forced him."

ɹænd pʊld ɪz hæn fɹi. ðə bɹæn lʊkt ə wik oʊld əɹ mɔɹ, ɔl bʌt hild. "wʌt dʒju min?" hi dɪmændəd.

Rand pulled his hand free. The brand looked a week old or more, all but healed. "What do you mean?" he demanded.

ʃi smaɪld ət hɪm, ən i fɛlt əʃeɪmd ə hɪz aʊtbɝst. "waɪ, ðə hɔɹn, ʌv kɔɹs," ʃi sɛd kɑmli, pʊɾɪŋ əweɪ hɝ sɑv. hɝ mɛɹ, stɛpɪŋ əlɔŋ bɪsaɪd ɹɛd, wɑz tɔl ɪnʌf ðəɾ əɹ aɪz wɝ oʊnli ə lɪɾəl bɪloʊ ɹænz. "ɪf jə faɪn ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ, ðəɹ wɪl bi noʊ əvɔɪɾɪŋ ɡɹeɪtnəs. bʌt wɪl ɪt bi fɔɹst ɑn ju, əɹ wɪl jə teɪk ɪt? ðæts ðə kwɛstʃən."

She smiled at him, and he felt ashamed of his outburst. "Why, the Horn, of course," she said calmly, putting away her salve. Her mare, stepping along beside Red, was tall enough that her eyes were only a little below Rand's. "If you find the Horn of Valere, there will be no avoiding greatness. But will it be forced on you, or will you take it? That's the question."

hi flɛkst ɪz hænd. ʃi saʊndəd soʊ mʌtʃ laɪk mɔɪɹeɪn. "ɑɹ jə ɛɛs sədaɪ?"

He flexed his hand. She sounded so much like Moiraine. "Are you Aes Sedai?"

səlinz aɪbɹaʊz lɪftəd; hɝ dɑɹk aɪz ɡlɪɾɝd ət hɪm, bʌɾ əɹ vɔɪs wɑz sɑft. "ɛɛs sədaɪ? aɪ? noʊ."

Selene's eyebrows lifted; her dark eyes glittered at him, but her voice was soft. "Aes Sedai? I? No."

"aɪ dɪdn min tə əfɛn ju. aɪm sɑɹi."

"I didn't mean to offend you. I'm sorry."

"əfɛn mi? aɪm nɑɾ əfɛndəd, bʌɾ ɪm noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ." hɝ lɪp kɝld ɪn ə snɪɹ; ivən ðət wɑz bjuɾəfəl. "ðeɪ kaʊɝ ɪn wʌt ðeɪ θɪŋk ɪz seɪfti wən ðeɪ kəd də soʊ mʌtʃ. ðeɪ sɝv wən ðeɪ kəd ɹul, lɛt mɛn faɪt wɔɹz wən ðeɪ kəd bɹɪŋ ɔɹɾɝ tə ðə wɝld. noʊ, nɛvɝ kɔl mi ɛɛs sədaɪ." ʃi smaɪld ən leɪɾ əɹ hæn ɑn ɪz ɑɹm tə ʃoʊ ʃi wɑz nɑɾ æŋɡɹi - hɝ tʌtʃ meɪɾ ɪm swɑloʊ - bʌɾ i wɑz ɹɪlivd wən ʃi lɛt ðə mɛɹ dʒɹɑp bæk bɪsaɪd lɔɪəl. hʊɹɪn bɑbd ɪz hɛɾ əɾ əɹ laɪk ən oʊl fæmli ɹɪteɪnɝ.

"Offend me? I am not offended, but I'm no Aes Sedai." Her lip curled in a sneer; even that was beautiful. "They cower in what they think is safety when they could do so much. They serve when they could rule, let men fight wars when they could bring order to the world. No, never call me Aes Sedai." She smiled and laid her hand on his arm to show she was not angry - her touch made him swallow - but he was relieved when she let the mare drop back beside Loial. Hurin bobbed his head at her like an old family retainer.

ɹænd wɑz ɹɪlivd, bʌɾ i mɪst əɹ pɹɛzəns, tu. ʃi wɑz oʊnli tu spænz əweɪ - hi twɪstəɾ ɪn ɪz sæɾəl tə stɛɹ ət hɝ, ɹaɪɾɪŋ baɪ lɔɪəlz saɪd; ði oʊɡiɝ wɑz bɛn hæf dʌbəl ɪn ɪz sæɾəl soʊ hi kəd tɔk wɪð əɹ - bʌt ðət wɑz nɑt ðə seɪm əz biɪŋ ɹaɪt ðəɹ bɪsaɪd hɪm, kloʊs ɪnʌf fəɹ ɪm tə smɛl əɹ hɛɾi sɛnt, kloʊs ɪnʌf tə tʌtʃ. hi sɛɾəld bæk æŋɡɹəli. ɪt wɑz nɑt ðəɾ i wɑntəd tə tʌtʃ hɝ, ɪɡzækli - hi ɹimaɪndəd hɪmsɛlf ðəɾ i lʌvd ɛɡwin; hi fɛlt ɡɪlti ət ðə nid fəɹ ɹimaɪndɪŋ - bʌt ʃi wɑz bjuɾəfəl, ən ʃi θɔɾ i wɑz ə lɔɹd, ən ʃi sɛɾ i kəd bi ə ɡɹeɪt mæn. hi ɑɹɡjud saʊɝli wɪð hɪmsɛlf ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz hɛd. mɔɪɹeɪn sɛz jə kən bi ɡɹeɪt, tu; ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. səlin ɪz nɑɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðæts ɹaɪt; ʃiz ə kɛɹhinɪn noʊbəlwʊmən, ən jəɹ ə ʃɛpɝd. ʃi dʌznt noʊ ðæt. haʊ lɔŋ dʒju lɛɾ əɹ bɪliv ə laɪ? ɪts oʊnli tɪl wi ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə ðɪs pleɪs. ɪf wi ɡɛɾ aʊt. ɪf. ɑn ðət noʊt, hɪz θɔts səbsaɪɾɪd tə sʌlən saɪləns.

Rand was relieved, but he missed her presence, too. She was only two spans away - he twisted in his saddle to stare at her, riding by Loial's side; the Ogier was bent half double in his saddle so he could talk with her - but that was not the same as being right there beside him, close enough for him to smell her heady scent, close enough to touch. He settled back angrily. It was not that he wanted to touch her, exactly - he reminded himself that he loved Egwene; he felt guilty at the need for reminding - but she was beautiful, and she thought he was a lord, and she said he could be a great man. He argued sourly with himself inside his head. Moiraine says you can be great, too; the Dragon Reborn. Selene is not Aes Sedai. That's right; she's a Cairhienin noblewoman, and you're a shepherd. She doesn't know that. How long do you let her believe a lie? It's only till we get out of this place. If we get out. If. On that note, his thoughts subsided to sullen silence.

hi tʃɹaɪd tə kip ə wɑtʃ ɑn ðə kʌntʃɹi θɹu wɪtʃ ðeɪ ɹoʊd - ɪf səlin sɛd ðəɹ wɝ mɔɹ ə ðoʊz θɪŋz . . . ðoʊz ɡɹoʊm . . . əbaʊt, hi bɪliv hɝ, ən hʊɹɪn wɑz tu ɪntɛn ɑn smɛlɪŋ ðə tʃɹeɪl tə noʊɾəs ɛniθɪŋ ɛls; lɔɪəl wɑz tu ɹæpt ʌp ɪn ɪz tɔk wɪð səlin tə si ɛniθɪŋ əntɪl ɪt bɪɾ ɪm ɑn ðə hil - bʌɾ ɪt wɑz hɑɹd tə wɑtʃ. tɝnɪŋ ɪz hɛd tu kwɪkli meɪɾ ɪz aɪz wɔɾɝ; ə hɪl əɹ ə stæn ə tʃɹiz kəd sim ə maɪl ɔf wən sin fɹəm wʌn æŋɡəl ən oʊnli ə fju hʌnʒɹəd spænz wən sin fɹəm ənʌðɝ.

He tried to keep a watch on the country through which they rode - if Selene said there were more of those things . . . those grolm . . . about, he believed her, and Hurin was too intent on smelling the trail to notice anything else; Loial was too wrapped up in his talk with Selene to see anything until it bit him on the heel - but it was hard to watch. Turning his head too quickly made his eyes water; a hill or a stand of trees could seem a mile off when seen from one angle and only a few hundred spans when seen from another.

ðə maʊntənz wɝ ɡɹoʊɪŋ kloʊsɝ, ʌv ðət mʌtʃ i wɑz ʃʊɹ. kɪnsleɪɝz dæɡɝ, lumɪŋ əɡɛns ðə skaɪ naʊ, ə sɔtuθ ɪkspæns ə snoʊ-kæpt piks. ðə læn ɝaʊn əm ɔlɹɛɾi ɹoʊz ɪn fʊthɪlz hɛɹəldɪŋ ðə kʌmɪŋ ə ðə maʊntənz. ðeɪ wəd ɹitʃ ði ɛdʒ ə ðə maʊntənz pɹɑpɝ wɛl bɪfɔɹ dɑɹk, pɝhæps ɪn oʊnli ənʌðɝ aʊɝ əɹ soʊ. mɔɹ ðən ə hʌnʒɹəd liɡz ɪn lɛs ðən θɹi deɪz. wɝs ðən ðæt. wi spɛn moʊst ʌv ə deɪ saʊθ ə ði ɛɹɪnɪn ɪn ðə ɹil wɝld. oʊvɝ ə hʌnʒɹəd liɡz ɪn lɛs ðən tu deɪz, hɪɹ.

The mountains were growing closer, of that much he was sure. Kinslayer's Dagger, looming against the sky now, a sawtooth expanse of snow-capped peaks. The land around them already rose in foothills heralding the coming of the mountains. They would reach the edge of the mountains proper well before dark, perhaps in only another hour or so. More than a hundred leagues in less than three days. Worse than that. We spent most of a day south of the Erinin in the real world. Over a hundred leagues in less than two days, here.

"ʃi sɛz jə wɝ ɹaɪɾ əbaʊt ðɪs pleɪs, ɹænd."

"She says you were right about this place, Rand."

ɹænd ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt bɪfɔɹ i ɹilaɪz lɔɪəl hæd ɹɪɾən ʌp bɪsaɪd hɪm. hi lʊk fəɹ səlin ən faʊn əɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ wɪð hʊɹɪn; ðə snɪfɝ wɑz ɡɹɪnɪŋ ən dʌkɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ ən ɔl bʌt nʌklɪŋ ɪz fɔɹhɛɾ əɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ʃi sɛd. ɹænd ɡlænst saɪdweɪz ət ði oʊɡiɝ. "aɪm sɝpɹaɪz jə kəd lɛɾ əɹ ɡoʊ, ðə weɪ jə tu hæd jəɹ hɛdz təɡɛðɝ. wʌt dʒju min, aɪ wɑz ɹaɪt?"

Rand gave a start before he realized Loial had ridden up beside him. He looked for Selene and found her riding with Hurin; the sniffer was grinning and ducking his head and all but knuckling his forehead at everything she said. Rand glanced sideways at the Ogier. "I'm surprised you could let her go, the way you two had your heads together. What do you mean, I was right?"

"ʃi ɪz ə fæsəneɪɾɪŋ wʊmən, ɪzənt ʃi? səm ə ði ɛldɝz doʊnt noʊ əz mʌtʃ əz ʃi dʌz əbaʊt hɪstɝi - ɪspɛʃli ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz - ən əbaʊt - oʊ, jɛs. ʃi sɛz jə wɝ ɹaɪɾ əbaʊt ðə weɪz, ɹænd. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, səm ə ðɛm, stʌɾid wɝlz laɪk ðɪs, ən ðət stʌɾi wɑz ðə beɪsəs ə haʊ ðeɪ ɡɹu ðə weɪz. ʃi sɛz ðəɹ ɑɹ wɝlz wɛɹ ɪts taɪm ɹæðɝ ðən dɪstəns ðət tʃeɪnʒəz. spɛn ə deɪ ɪn wʌn ə ðoʊz, ən jə maɪt kʌm bæk tə faɪn ə jɪɹ əz pæst ɪn ðə ɹil wɝld, əɹ twɛnti. əɹ ɪt kəd bi ði ʌðɝ weɪ ɹaʊnd. ðoʊz wɝlz - ðɪs wʌn, ɔl ði ʌðɝz - ɑɹ ɹɪflɛkʃənz ə ðə ɹil wɝld, ʃi sɛz. ðɪs wʌn simz peɪl tə əs kəz ɪts ə wik ɹəflɛkʃən, ə wɝl ðət hæd lɪɾəl tʃæns ʌv ɛvɝ biɪŋ. ʌðɝz ɑɹ ɔlmoʊst əz laɪkli əz aʊɝz. ðoʊz ɑɹ əz sɑləɾ əz əɹ wɝld, ən əv pipəl. ðə seɪm pipəl, ʃi sɛz, ɹænd. ɪmædʒən ɪt! jə kəd ɡoʊ tə wʌn ə ðɛm ən mit jɝsɛlf. ðə pæɾɝn əz ɪnfənət vɛɹieɪʃən, ʃi sɛz, ən ɛvɹi vɛɹieɪʃən ðət kən bi, wɪl bi."

"She is a fascinating woman, isn't she? Some of the Elders don't know as much as she does about history - especially the Age of Legends - and about - oh, yes. She says you were right about the Ways, Rand. The Aes Sedai, some of them, studied worlds like this, and that study was the basis of how they grew the Ways. She says there are worlds where it is time rather than distance that changes. Spend a day in one of those, and you might come back to find a year has passed in the real world, or twenty. Or it could be the other way round. Those worlds - this one, all the others - are reflections of the real world, she says. This one seems pale to us because it is a weak reflection, a world that had little chance of ever being. Others are almost as likely as ours. Those are as solid as our world, and have people. The same people, she says, Rand. Imagine it! You could go to one of them and meet yourself. The Pattern has infinite variation, she says, and every variation that can be, will be."

ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, ðən wɪʃt i hæd nɑɾ əz ðə lændskeɪp flɪkɝd bæk ən fɔɹθ ən ɪz stʌmək lɝtʃt. hi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. "haʊ dʌz ʃi noʊ ɔl ðæt? jə noʊ əbaʊt mɔɹ θɪŋz ðən ɛnibəɾi aɪ ɛvɝ mɛt bɪfɔɹ, lɔɪəl, ən ɔl jə nu əbaʊt ðɪs wɝld əmaʊntɪd tə noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə ɹumɝ."

Rand shook his head, then wished he had not as the landscape flickered back and forth and his stomach lurched. He took a deep breath. "How does she know all that? You know about more things than anybody I ever met before, Loial, and all you knew about this world amounted to no more than a rumor."

"ʃiz kɛɹhinɪn, ɹænd. ðə ɹɔɪəl laɪbɹɛɹi ɪn kɛɹhin ɪz wʌn ə ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst ɪn ðə wɝld, pɝhæps ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst aʊtsaɪd tɑɹ vəlɑn. ði il spɛɹɾ ɪt dɪlɪbɝətli, jə noʊ, wən ðeɪ bɝn kɛɹhin. ðəl nɑt dɪstʃɹɔɪ ə bʊk. dɪd jə noʊ ðət ðeɪ - "

"She's Cairhienin, Rand. The Royal Library in Cairhien is one of the greatest in the world, perhaps the greatest outside Tar Valon. The Aiel spared it deliberately, you know, when they burned Cairhien. They will not destroy a book. Did you know that they - "

"aɪ doʊn kɛɹ əbaʊɾ ilmɛn," ɹænd sɛd hɑtli. "ɪf səlin noʊz soʊ mʌtʃ, aɪ hoʊp ʃi ɹɛd haʊ tə ɡɛɾ əs hoʊm fɹəm hɪɹ. aɪ wɪʃ səlin - "

"I don't care about Aielmen," Rand said hotly. "If Selene knows so much, I hope she read how to get us home from here. I wish Selene - "

"ju wɪʃ səlin wʌt?" ðə wʊmən læft əz ʃi dʒɔɪn ðɛm.

"You wish Selene what?" The woman laughed as she joined them.

ɹænd stɛɹɾ əɾ əɹ əz ɪf ʃi hæd bɪn ɡɔn mʌnθs; ðət wɑz haʊ hi fɛlt. "aɪ wɪʃ səlin wəd kʌm ɹaɪd wɪð mi səm mɔɹ," hi sɛd. lɔɪəl tʃʌkəld, ən ɹænd fɛlt ɪz feɪs bɝn.

Rand stared at her as if she had been gone months; that was how he felt. "I wish Selene would come ride with me some more," he said. Loial chuckled, and Rand felt his face burn.

səlin smaɪld, ən lʊkt ət lɔɪəl. "ju wɪl ɪkskjuz ʌs, ælɑntɪn."

Selene smiled, and looked at Loial. "You will excuse us, alantin."

ði oʊɡiɝ baʊɾ ɪn ɪz sæɾəl ən lɛɾ ɪz bɪɡ hɔɹs fɔl bæk, ðə tʌfs ɑn ɪz ɪɹz dʒɹupɪŋ wɪð ɹɪlʌktəns.

The Ogier bowed in his saddle and let his big horse fall back, the tufts on his ears drooping with reluctance.

fəɹ ə taɪm ɹænd ɹoʊɾ ɪn saɪləns, ɛndʒɔɪɪŋ səlinz pɹɛzəns. naʊ ən əɡɛn i lʊkt əɾ əɹ aʊɾ ə ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz aɪ. hi wɪʃt i kəd ɡɛɾ ɪz filɪŋz əbaʊɾ əɹ stʃɹeɪt. kəd ʃi bi ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, dɪspaɪɾ əɹ dɪnaɪəl? sʌmwʌn sɛn baɪ mɔɪɹeɪn tə pʊʃ ɪm əlɔŋ wʌtɛvɝ pæθ i wɑz mɛn tə fɑloʊ ɪn ði ɛɛs sədaɪz plænz? mɔɪɹeɪn kəd nɑɾ əv noʊn i wəd bi teɪkən tə ðɪs stʃɹeɪnʒ wɝld, ən noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ wʊɾə tʃɹaɪd tə fɛn ɔf ðət bist wɪð ə stɪk wən ʃi kəd stʃɹaɪk ɪt dɛɾ əɹ sɛn ɪt ɹʌnɪŋ wɪð ðə paʊɝ. wɛl. sɪns ʃi tʊk ɪm fəɹ ə lɔɹɾ ən noʊ wʌn ɪn kɛɹhin nu dɪfɹənt, hi maɪt kip ɑn lɛɾɪŋ əɹ θɪŋk ɪt. ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹli ðə moʊs bjuɾəfəl wʊmən i hæɾ ɛvɝ sin, ɪntɛlədʒən ən lɝnd, ən ʃi θɔɾ i wɑz bɹeɪv; wʌt mɔɹ kəɾ ə mæn æsk fɹəm ə waɪf? ðæts kɹeɪzi, tu. aɪd mɛɹi ɛɡwin ɪf aɪ kəd mɛɹi ɛniwʌn, bʌɾ aɪ kæn æsk ə wʊmən tə mɛɹi ə mæn huz gɑnə ɡoʊ mæd, meɪbi hɝt hɝ. bʌt səlin wɑz soʊ bjuɾəfəl.

For a time Rand rode in silence, enjoying Selene's presence. Now and again he looked at her out of the corner of his eye. He wished he could get his feelings about her straight. Could she be an Aes Sedai, despite her denial? Someone sent by Moiraine to push him along whatever path he was meant to follow in the Aes Sedai's plans? Moiraine could not have known he would be taken to this strange world, and no Aes Sedai would have tried to fend off that beast with a stick when she could strike it dead or send it running with the Power. Well. Since she took him for a lord and no one in Cairhien knew different, he might keep on letting her think it. She was surely the most beautiful woman he had ever seen, intelligent and learned, and she thought he was brave; what more could a man ask from a wife? That's crazy, too. I'd marry Egwene if I could marry anyone, but I can't ask a woman to marry a man who's going to go mad, maybe hurt her. But Selene was so beautiful.

ʃi wɑz stʌɾiɪŋ ɪz sɔɹd, hi sɔ. hi ɹɛɾid ðə wɝdz ɪn ɪz hɛd. noʊ, hi wɑz nɑɾ ə bleɪdmæstɝ, bʌɾ ɪz fɑðɝ hæd ɡɪvən ɪm ðə sɔɹd. tæm. laɪt, waɪ kʊdn jə ɹɪli bi maɪ fɑðɝ? hi skwɑʃt ðə θɔt ɹuθləsli.

She was studying his sword, he saw. He readied the words in his head. No, he was not a blademaster, but his father had given him the sword. Tam. Light, why couldn't you really be my father? He squashed the thought ruthlessly.

"ðæt wɑz ə mæɡnɪfəsənt ʃɑt," səlin sɛd.

"That was a magnificent shot," Selene said.

"noʊ, aɪm nɑɾ ə - " ɹænd bɪɡæn, ðən blɪŋkt. "ə ʃɑt?"

"No, I'm not a - " Rand began, then blinked. "A shot?"

"jɛs. ə taɪni tɑɹɡət, ðəɾ aɪ, muvɪŋ, əɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz. juv ə wʌndɝfəl hænd wɪð ðət baʊ."

"Yes. A tiny target, that eye, moving, at a hundred paces. You've a wonderful hand with that bow."

ɹænd ʃɪftəɾ ɔkwɝdli. "ɑ . . . θæŋk ju. ɪts ə tʃɹɪk maɪ fɑðɝ tɔt mi." hi toʊld əɹ əbaʊt ðə vɔɪd, əbaʊt haʊ tæm hæd tɔɾ ɪm haʊ tə juz ɪt wɪð ðə baʊ. hi ivən faʊn hɪmsɛlf tɛlɪŋ əɹ əbaʊt læn ən ɪz sɔɹd lɛsənz.

Rand shifted awkwardly. "Ah . . . thank you. It's a trick my father taught me." He told her about the void, about how Tam had taught him how to use it with the bow. He even found himself telling her about Lan and his sword lessons.

"ðə wʌnnəs," ʃi sɛd, saʊndɪŋ sæɾəsfaɪd. ʃi sɔ hɪz kwɛstʃənɪŋ lʊk ən æɾəd, "ðæɾ ɪz wʌɾ ɪts kɔld . . . ɪn səm pleɪsəz. ðə wʌnnəs. tə lɝn ðə fʊl jus ʌv ɪt, ɪts bɛs tə ɹæp ɪɾ ɝaʊn jə kəntɪnjuəsli, tə dwɛl ɪn ɪɾ əɾ ɔl taɪmz, əɹ soʊ aɪv hɝd."

"The Oneness," she said, sounding satisfied. She saw his questioning look and added, "That is what it is called . . . in some places. The Oneness. To learn the full use of it, it is best to wrap it around you continuously, to dwell in it at all times, or so I've heard."

hi dɪd nɑɾ ivən əv tə θɪŋk əbaʊt wʌt leɪ weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɪm ɪn ðə vɔɪd tə noʊ hɪz ænsɝ tə ðæt, bʌt wʌɾ i sɛd wɑz, "aɪl θɪŋk əbaʊɾ ɪt."

He did not even have to think about what lay waiting for him in the void to know his answer to that, but what he said was, "I'll think about it."

"wɛɹ ðɪs vɔɪɾ ə jʊɹz ɔl ðə taɪm, ɹænd ælθɹ, ən jəl lɝn jusəz fəɹ ɪt jə nɛvɝ səspɛktəd."

"Wear this void of yours all the time, Rand al'Thor, and you'll learn uses for it you never suspected."

"aɪ sɛɾ əl θɪŋk əbaʊɾ ɪt." ʃi oʊpən əɹ maʊθ əɡɛn, bʌɾ i kʌɾ əɹ ɔf. "ju noʊ ɔl ðiz θɪŋz. əbaʊt ðə vɔɪd - ðə wʌnnəs, jə kɔl ɪt. əbaʊt ðɪs wɝld. lɔɪəl ɹidz bʊks ɔl ðə taɪm; hiz ɹɛd mɔɹ bʊks ðən aɪv ɛvɝ sin, ən hiz nɛvɝ sin ɛniθɪŋ bʌɾ ə fɹæɡmən əbaʊt ðə stoʊnz."

"I said I will think about it." She opened her mouth again, but he cut her off. "You know all these things. About the void - the Oneness, you call it. About this world. Loial reads books all the time; he's read more books than I've ever seen, and he's never seen anything but a fragment about the Stones."

səlin dʒɹu hɝsɛlf ʌp stʃɹeɪɾ ɪn əɹ sæɾəl. sʌɾənli ʃi ɹimaɪndəɾ ɪm ə mɔɪɹeɪn, ən ə kwin mɔɹɡeɪs, wən ðeɪ wɝ æŋɡɹi.

Selene drew herself up straight in her saddle. Suddenly she reminded him of Moiraine, and of Queen Morgase, when they were angry.

"ðɛɹ wɑz ə bʊk ɹɪɾən əbaʊt ðiz wɝlz," ʃi sɛd taɪtli. "mɪɹɝz ə ðə wil. jə si, ði ælɑntɪn əz nɑt sin ɔl ðə bʊks ðəɾ ɑɹ."

"There was a book written about these worlds," she said tightly. "Mirrors of the Wheel. You see, the alantin has not seen all the books that are."

"wʌɾ ɪz ðɪs ælɑntɪn jə kɔl hɪm? aɪv nɛvɝ hɝd - "

"What is this alantin you call him? I've never heard - "

"ðə pɔɹɾəl stoʊn bɪsaɪd wɪtʃ aɪ woʊk ɪz ʌp ðɛɹ," səlin sɛd, pɔɪntɪŋ ɪndə ðə maʊntənz, ɔf tə ði ist ə ðɛɹ pæθ. ɹænd faʊn hɪmsɛlf wɪʃɪŋ fəɹ əɹ wɔɹmθ əɡɛn, ən əɹ smaɪlz. "ɪf jə teɪk mi tə ɪt, jə kən ɹɪtɝn mi tə maɪ hoʊm, əz jə pɹɑməst. wi kən ɹitʃ ɪɾ ɪn ən aʊɝ."

"The Portal Stone beside which I woke is up there," Selene said, pointing into the mountains, off to the east of their path. Rand found himself wishing for her warmth again, and her smiles. "If you take me to it, you can return me to my home, as you promised. We can reach it in an hour."

ɹænd bɛɹli lʊkt wɛɹ ʃi pɔɪntəd. juzɪŋ ðə stoʊn - pɔɹɾəl stoʊn, ʃi kɔld ɪt - mɛnt wildɪŋ ðə paʊɝ, ɪf i wɝ tə teɪk əɹ bæk tə ðə ɹil wɝld. "hʊɹɪn, haʊ ɪz ðə tʃɹeɪl?"

Rand barely looked where she pointed. Using the Stone - Portal Stone, she called it - meant wielding the Power, if he were to take her back to the real world. "Hurin, how is the trail?"

"feɪntɝ ðən ɛvɝ, lɔɹd ɹænd, bʌt stɪl ðɛɹ." ðə snɪfɝ spɛɹɾ ə kwɪk ɡɹɪn ən bɑb ə hɪz hɛd fəɹ səlin. "aɪ θɪŋk ɪts stɑɹɾɪŋ tə æŋɡəl ɔf tə ðə wɛst. ðɛɹz səm iziɝ pæsəz ðɛɹ, təwɔɹd ðə tɪp ə ðə dæɡɝ, əz aɪ ɹikɔl fɹəm wən aɪ wɛn tə kɛɹhin ðət taɪm."

"Fainter than ever, Lord Rand, but still there." The sniffer spared a quick grin and bob of his head for Selene. "I think it's starting to angle off to the west. There's some easier passes there, toward the tip of the Dagger, as I recall from when I went to Cairhien that time."

ɹænd saɪd. feɪn, əɹ wʌn ə hɪz dɑɹkfɹɛnz, hæz tə noʊ ənʌðɝ weɪ tə juz ðə stoʊnz. eɪ dɑɹkfɹɛn kʊdn juz ðə paʊɝ. "aɪ hæv tə fɑloʊ ðə hɔɹn, səlin."

Rand sighed. Fain, or one of his Darkfriends, has to know another way to use the Stones. A Darkfriend couldn't use the Power. "I have to follow the Horn, Selene."

"haʊ dʒju noʊ jəɹ pɹɛʃəs hɔɹn ɪz ivən ɪn ðɪs wɝld? kʌm wɪð mi, ɹænd. jəl faɪn jəɹ lɛdʒənd, aɪ pɹɑməs ju. kʌm wɪð mi."

"How do you know your precious Horn is even in this world? Come with me, Rand. You'll find your legend, I promise you. Come with me."

"ju kən juz ðə stoʊn, ðɪs pɔɹɾəl stoʊn, jɝsɛlf," hi sɛɾ æŋɡɹəli. bɪfɔɹ ðə wɝdz wɝ aʊɾ ə hɪz maʊθ i wɑntəɾ əm bæk. waɪ dʌz ʃi hæv tə kip tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt lɛdʒənz? stʌbɝnli, hi fɔɹs hɪmsɛlf tə ɡoʊ ɑn. "ðə pɔɹɾəl stoʊn dɪdn bɹɪŋ jə hɪɹ baɪ ɪtsɛlf. jə dɪɾ ɪt, səlin. ɪf jə meɪd ðə stoʊn bɹɪŋ jə hɪɹ, jə kən meɪk ɪt teɪk jə bæk. əl teɪk jə tə ɪt, bʌt ðən aɪ mʌst ɡoʊ ɑn æftɝ ðə hɔɹn."

"You can use the Stone, this Portal Stone, yourself," he said angrily. Before the words were out of his mouth he wanted them back. Why does she have to keep talking about legends? Stubbornly, he forced himself to go on. "The Portal Stone didn't bring you here by itself. You did it, Selene. If you made the Stone bring you here, you can make it take you back. I'll take you to it, but then I must go on after the Horn."

"aɪ noʊ nʌθɪŋ əbaʊt juzɪŋ ðə pɔɹɾəl stoʊnz, ɹænd. ɪf aɪ dɪɾ ɛniθɪŋ, aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌɾ ɪt wɑz."

"I know nothing about using the Portal Stones, Rand. If I did anything, I don't know what it was."

ɹænd stʌɾid hɝ. ʃi sæɾ əɹ sæɾəl, stʃɹeɪt-bækt ən tɔl, dʒʌst əz ɹiɡəli əz bɪfɔɹ, bʌt sʌmhaʊ sɑftɝ, tu. pɹaʊd, jɛt vʌlnɝəbəl, ən niɾɪŋ hɪm. hi hæd pʊt nɪneɪivz eɪdʒ tə hɝ - ə hændfʊl ə jɪɹz oʊldɝ ðən hɪmsɛlf - bʌɾ i hæd bɪn ɹɔŋ, hi ɹilaɪzd. ʃi wɑz mɔɹ ɪz oʊn eɪdʒ, ən bjuɾəfəl, ən ʃi niɾəd hɪm. ðə θɔt, dʒʌs ðə θɔt, ʌv ðə vɔɪd flɪkɝd θɹu hɪz hɛd, ən ə ðə laɪt. seɪɾɪn. tə juz ðə pɔɹɾəl stoʊn, hi mʌs dɪp hɪmsɛlf bæk ɪndə ðət teɪnt.

Rand studied her. She sat her saddle, straight-backed and tall, just as regally as before, but somehow softer, too. Proud, yet vulnerable, and needing him. He had put Nynaeve's age to her - a handful of years older than himself - but he had been wrong, he realized. She was more his own age, and beautiful, and she needed him. The thought, just the thought, of the void flickered through his head, and of the light. Saidin. To use the Portal Stone, he must dip himself back into that taint.

"steɪ wɪð mi, səlin," hi sɛd. "wil faɪn ðə hɔɹn, ən mæts dæɡɝ, ən wɪl faɪn ə weɪ bæk. aɪ pɹɑməs ju. dʒʌst steɪ wɪð mi."

"Stay with me, Selene," he said. "We'll find the Horn, and Mat's dagger, and we'll find a way back. I promise you. Just stay with me."

"ju ɔlweɪz. . . ." səlin dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ əz ɪf tə kɑm hɝsɛlf. "ju ɔlweɪz ɑɹ soʊ stʌbɝn. wɛl, aɪ kən ædmaɪɹ stʌbɝnnəs ɪn ə mæn. ðəɹ ɪz lɪɾəl tə ə mæn huz tu izəli bɪɾəbəl."

"You always. . . ." Selene drew a deep breath as if to calm herself. "You always are so stubborn. Well, I can admire stubbornness in a man. There is little to a man who's too easily biddable."

ɹænd kʌlɝd; ɪt wɑz tu mʌtʃ laɪk ðə θɪŋz ɛɡwin səmtaɪmz sɛd, ən ðeɪ hæɾ ɔl bʌt bɪn pɹɑməst ɪn mɛɹɪdʒ sɪns ðeɪ wɝ tʃɪlʒɹən. fɹəm səlin, ðə wɝdz, ən ðə dɝɛk lʊk ðət wɛnt wɪð ðɛm, wɝ ə ʃɑk. hi tɝn tə tɛl hʊɹɪn tə pɹɛs ɑn wɪð ðə tʃɹeɪl.

Rand colored; it was too much like the things Egwene sometimes said, and they had all but been promised in marriage since they were children. From Selene, the words, and the direct look that went with them, were a shock. He turned to tell Hurin to press on with the trail.

fɹəm bɪhaɪn əm keɪm ə dɪstənt, kɑfɪŋ ɡɹʌnt. bɪfɔɹ ɹænd kəd wɝl ɹɛd tə lʊk, ənʌðɝ bɑɹk saʊndəd, ən θɹi mɔɹ ɑn ɪts hilz. ət fɝst i kəd meɪk aʊt nʌθɪŋ əz ðə lændskeɪp sim tə weɪvɝ ɪn ɪz aɪz, bʌt ðən i sɔ ðɛm θɹu ðə waɪdspɹɛd stænz ə tʃɹiz, dʒʌs tɑpɪŋ ə hɪl. faɪv ʃeɪps, ɪt simd, oʊnli hæf ə maɪl dɪstənt, ə bɛɹ θaʊzən peɪsɪz ət moʊst, ən kʌmɪŋ ɪn θɝɾi-fʊt baʊnz.

From behind them came a distant, coughing grunt. Before Rand could whirl Red to look, another bark sounded, and three more on its heels. At first he could make out nothing as the landscape seemed to waver in his eyes, but then he saw them through the widespread stands of trees, just topping a hill. Five shapes, it seemed, only half a mile distant, a bare thousand paces at most, and coming in thirty-foot bounds.

"ɡɹoʊm," səlin sɛd kɑmli. "ə smɔl pæk, bʌt ðeɪv əɹ sɛnt, ɪt simz."

"Grolm," Selene said calmly. "A small pack, but they have our scent, it seems."


tʃæptɝ sɛvəntin


CHAPTER 17

tʃɔɪsəz


Choices

"wil ɹʌn fəɹ ɪt," ɹænd sɛd. "hʊɹɪn, kən jə ɡæləp ən stɪl fɑloʊ ðə tʃɹeɪl?"

"We'll run for it," Rand said. "Hurin, can you gallop and still follow the trail?"

"jɛs, lɔɹd ɹænd."

"Yes, Lord Rand."

"ðɛn pʊʃ ɑn. wɪl - "

"Then push on. We will - "

"ɪt woʊn də ɛni ɡʊd," səlin sɛd. hɝ waɪt mɛɹ wɑz ði oʊnli wʌn ə ðɛɹ maʊns nɑt dænsɪŋ ət ðə ɡɹʌf bɑɹks kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ðə ɡɹoʊm. "ðeɪ doʊnt ɡɪv ʌp, nɑɾ ɛvɝ. wʌns ðeɪv jəɹ sɛnt, ɡɹoʊm kip kʌmɪŋ, deɪ ən naɪt, əntɪl ðeɪ ɹʌn jə daʊn. jə mʌs kɪl əm ɔl, əɹ faɪn ə weɪ tə ɡoʊ ɛlswɛɹ. ɹænd, ðə pɔɹɾəl stoʊn kən teɪk əs ɛlswɛɹ."

"It won't do any good," Selene said. Her white mare was the only one of their mounts not dancing at the gruff barks coming from the grolm. "They don't give up, not ever. Once they have your scent, grolm keep coming, day and night, until they run you down. You must kill them all, or find a way to go elsewhere. Rand, the Portal Stone can take us elsewhere."

"noʊ! wi kən kɪl ðɛm. aɪ kæn. aɪ ɔlɹɛɾi kɪld wʌn. ðəɹ ɑɹ oʊnli faɪv. ɪf aɪ kən dʒʌs faɪnd. . . ." hi kæst ɝaʊn fəɹ ðə spɑɾ i niɾəd, ən faʊn ɪt. "fɑloʊ mi!" dɪɡɪŋ ɪz hilz ɪn, hi sɛt ɹɛd tə ə ɡæləp, kɑnfəɾənt bɪfɔɹ i hɝd ðɛɹ hʊvz ðət ði ʌðɝz wəd kʌm.

"No! We can kill them. I can. I already killed one. There are only five. If I can just find. . . ." He cast around for the spot he needed, and found it. "Follow me!" Digging his heels in, he set Red to a gallop, confident before he heard their hooves that the others would come.

ðə pleɪs i hæd tʃoʊzən wɑz ə loʊ, ɹaʊn hɪl, bɛɹ ə tʃɹiz. nʌθɪŋ kəd kʌm kloʊs wɪθaʊɾ ɪm siɪŋ. hi swʌŋ daʊn fɹəm ɪz sæɾəl ən ənlɪmbɝɾ ɪz lɔŋboʊ. lɔɪəl ən hʊɹɪn dʒɔɪn ɪm ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ði oʊɡiɝ hɛftɪŋ ɪz hjudʒ kɔɹɾɝstæf, ðə snɪfɝ wɪð ɪz ʃɔɹt sɔɹɾ ɪn ɪz fɪst. niðɝ kɔɹɾɝstæf nɔɹ sɔɹd wəd bi ʌv mʌtʃ jus ɪf ðə ɡɹoʊm kloʊzd wɪð ðɛm. aɪ woʊn lɛɾ əm ɡɛt kloʊs.

The place he had chosen was a low, round hill, bare of trees. Nothing could come close without him seeing. He swung down from his saddle and unlimbered his longbow. Loial and Hurin joined him on the ground, the Ogier hefting his huge quarterstaff, the sniffer with his short sword in his fist. Neither quarterstaff nor sword would be of much use if the grolm closed with them. I won't let them get close.

"ðɪs ɹɪsk ɪz nɑt nɛsəsɛɹi," səlin sɛd. ʃi bɛɹli lʊk təwɔɹd ðə ɡɹoʊm, bɛndɪŋ fɹəm əɹ sæɾəl tə kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾ ɑn ɹænd. "wi kən izəli ɹitʃ ðə pɔɹɾəl stoʊn əhɛɾ ə ðɛm."

"This risk is not necessary," Selene said. She barely looked toward the grolm, bending from her saddle to concentrate on Rand. "We can easily reach the Portal Stone ahead of them."

"aɪ wɪl stɑp ðɛm." heɪstəli ɹænd kaʊntəd ði æɹoʊz ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ ɪn ɪz kwɪvɝ. eɪtin, itʃ əz lɔŋ əz ɪz ɑɹm, tɛn ə ðɛm wɪð pɔɪns laɪk tʃɪzəlz, dɪzaɪn tə dʒɹaɪv θɹu tʃɹɑlɑk ɑɹmɝ. ðeɪ wəd də əz wɛl fəɹ ɡɹoʊm əz fəɹ tʃɹɑləks. hi stʌk fɔɹ ə ðoʊz əpɹaɪɾ ɪn ðə ɡɹaʊn ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm; ə fɪfθ i nɑk tə ðə baʊ. "lɔɪəl, hʊɹɪn, jə kən də noʊ ɡʊd daʊn hɪɹ. maʊn ən bi ɹɛɾi tə teɪk səlin tə ðə stoʊn ɪf ɛni ɡɛt θɹu." hi wʌndɝd wɛðɝ i kəd kɪl wʌn ə ðə θɪŋz wɪð ɪz sɔɹd, ɪf ɪt keɪm tə ðæt. jə ɑɹ mæd! ivən ðə paʊɝ ɪz nɑɾ əz bæɾ əz ðɪs.

"I will stop them." Hastily Rand counted the arrows remaining in his quiver. Eighteen, each as long as his arm, ten of them with points like chisels, designed to drive through Trolloc armor. They would do as well for grolm as for Trollocs. He stuck four of those upright in the ground in front of him; a fifth he nocked to the bow. "Loial, Hurin, you can do no good down here. Mount and be ready to take Selene to the Stone if any get through." He wondered whether he could kill one of the things with his sword, if it came to that. You are mad! Even the Power is not as bad as this.

lɔɪəl sɛd sʌmθɪŋ, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt hɪɹ; hi wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi sikɪŋ ðə vɔɪd, əz mʌtʃ tə ɪskeɪp ɪz oʊn θɔts əz fəɹ nid. jə noʊ wʌts weɪɾɪŋ. bʌt ðɪs weɪ aɪ doʊn əv tə tʌtʃ ɪt. ðə ɡloʊ wɑz ðɛɹ, ðə laɪt dʒʌst aʊɾ ə saɪt. ɪt sim tə floʊ təwɔɹd hɪm, bʌt ði ɛmptinəs wɑz ɔl. θɔts dɑɹɾɪd əkɹɔs ðə sɝfəs ə ðə vɔɪd, vɪzəbəl ɪn ðət teɪntɪd laɪt. seɪɾɪn. ðə paʊɝ. mædnəs. dɛθ. ɛkstʃɹeɪniəs θɔts. hi wɑz wʌn wɪð ðə baʊ, wɪð ði æɹoʊ, wɪð ðə θɪŋz tɑpɪŋ ðə nɛkst ɹaɪz.

Loial said something, but he did not hear; he was already seeking the void, as much to escape his own thoughts as for need. You know what's waiting. But this way I don't have to touch it. The glow was there, the light just out of sight. It seemed to flow toward him, but the emptiness was all. Thoughts darted across the surface of the void, visible in that tainted light. Saidin. The Power. Madness. Death. Extraneous thoughts. He was one with the bow, with the arrow, with the things topping the next rise.

ðə ɡɹoʊm keɪm ɑn, oʊvɝɹitʃɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝ ɪn ðɛɹ lips, faɪv ɡɹeɪt, lɛðɝi ʃeɪps, tʃɹɪpəl-aɪd, wɪð hɔɹni mɔz ɡeɪpɪŋ. ðɛɹ ɡɹʌntɪŋ kɔlz ɹɪbaʊndɪd fɹəm ðə vɔɪd, bɛɹli hɝd.

The grolm came on, overreaching one another in their leaps, five great, leathery shapes, triple-eyed, with horny maws gaping. Their grunting calls rebounded from the void, barely heard.

ɹænd wɑz nɑɾ əwɛɹ ə ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz baʊ, əɹ dʒɹɔɪŋ ðə flɛtʃɪŋ əɡɛnst ɪz tʃik, tə hɪz ɪɹ. hi wɑz wʌn wɪð ðə bists, wʌn wɪð ðə sɛntɝ aɪ ʌv ðə fɝst. ðən ði æɹoʊ wɑz ɡɔn. ðə fɝst ɡɹoʊm daɪd; wʌn ʌv ɪts kəmpænjənz lɛpt ɑn ɪɾ əz ɪt fɛl, bik ʌv ə maʊθ ɹɪpɪŋ ɡɑbɛts ə flɛʃ. ɪt snɑɹəld ət ði ʌðɝz, ən ðeɪ sɝkəld waɪd. bʌt ðeɪ keɪm ɑn, ən əz ɪf kəmpɛld, ɪɾ əbændən ɪts mil ən lɛpt æftɝ ðɛm, ɪts hɔɹni mɔ ɔlɹɛɾi blʌɾi.

Rand was not aware of raising his bow, or drawing the fletching against his cheek, to his ear. He was one with the beasts, one with the center eye of the first. Then the arrow was gone. The first grolm died; one of its companions leaped on it as it fell, beak of a mouth ripping gobbets of flesh. It snarled at the others, and they circled wide. But they came on, and as if compelled, it abandoned its meal and leaped after them, its horny maw already bloody.

ɹænd wɝk smuðli, ʌnkɑnʃəsli, nɑk ən ɹilis. nɑk ən ɹilis.

Rand worked smoothly, unconsciously, nock and release. Nock and release.

ðə fɪfθ æɹoʊ lɛft ɪz baʊ, ən i loʊɝɾ ɪt, stɪl dip ɪn ðə vɔɪd, əz ðə fɔɹθ ɡɹoʊm fɛl laɪk ə hjudʒ pʌpət wɪð ɪts stʃɹɪŋz kʌt. ðoʊ ðə faɪnəl æɹoʊ stɪl flu, sʌmhaʊ hi nu ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid fəɹ ənʌðɝ ʃɑt. ðə læs bis kəlæpst əz ɪf ɪts boʊnz hæd mɛltəd, ə fɛðɝd ʃæf dʒʌɾɪŋ fɹəm ɪts sɛntɝ aɪ. ɔlweɪz ðə sɛntɝ aɪ.

The fifth arrow left his bow, and he lowered it, still deep in the void, as the fourth grolm fell like a huge puppet with its strings cut. Though the final arrow still flew, somehow he knew there was no need for another shot. The last beast collapsed as if its bones had melted, a feathered shaft jutting from its center eye. Always the center eye.

"mæɡnɪfəsənt, lɔɹd ɹænd," hʊɹɪn sɛd. "aɪ . . . aɪv nɛvɝ sin ʃuɾɪŋ laɪk ðæt."

"Magnificent, Lord Rand," Hurin said. "I . . . I've never seen shooting like that."

ðə vɔɪd hɛld ɹænd. ðə laɪt kɔl tə hɪm, ən i . . . ɹitʃt . . . təwɔɹɾ ɪt. ɪt sɝaʊndəd hɪm, fɪl hɪm.

The void held Rand. The light called to him, and he . . . reached . . . toward it. It surrounded him, filled him.

"lɔɹd ɹænd?" hʊɹɪn tʌtʃt ɪz ɑɹm, ən ɹænd ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt, ði ɛmptinəs fɪlɪŋ ʌp wɪð wʌt wɑz ɝaʊn hɪm. "ɑɹ jə ɔl ɹaɪt, maɪ lɔɹd?"

"Lord Rand?" Hurin touched his arm, and Rand gave a start, the emptiness filling up with what was around him. "Are you all right, my Lord?"

ɹænd bɹʌʃt ɪz fɔɹhɛd wɪð fɪŋɡɝtɪps. ɪt wɑz dʒɹaɪ; hi fɛlt əz ɪf ɪt ʃʊɾə bɪn kʌvɝd wɪð swɛt. "aɪ. . . . aɪm faɪn, hʊɹɪn."

Rand brushed his forehead with fingertips. It was dry; he felt as if it should have been covered with sweat. "I. . . . I'm fine, Hurin."

"ɪt ɡɹoʊz iziɝ itʃ taɪm jə də ɪt, aɪv hɝd," səlin sɛd. "ðə mɔɹ jə lɪv ɪn ðə wʌnnəs, ði iziɝ."

"It grows easier each time you do it, I've heard," Selene said. "The more you live in the Oneness, the easier."

ɹænd ɡlænst ət hɝ. "wɛl, aɪ woʊnt niɾ ɪɾ əɡɛn, nɑt fəɹ ə waɪl." wʌt hæpənd? aɪ wɑntəd tə. . . . hi stɪl wɑntəd tə, hi ɹilaɪzd wɪð hɔɹɝ. hi wɑntəd tə ɡoʊ bæk ɪndə ðə vɔɪd, wɑntəd tə fil ðət laɪt fɪlɪŋ ɪm əɡɛn. ɪt hæd simd əz ɪf i wɝ tʃɹuli əlaɪv ðɛn, sɪklinəs ən ɔl, ən naʊ wɑz oʊnli ən ɪməteɪʃən. noʊ, wɝs. hi hæd bɪn ɔlmoʊst əlaɪv, noʊɪŋ wʌt "əlaɪv" wəd bi laɪk. ɔl i hæd tə də wɑz ɹitʃ aʊt tə seɪɾɪn. . . .

Rand glanced at her. "Well, I won't need it again, not for a while." What happened? I wanted to. . . . He still wanted to, he realized with horror. He wanted to go back into the void, wanted to feel that light filling him again. It had seemed as if he were truly alive then, sickliness and all, and now was only an imitation. No, worse. He had been almost alive, knowing what "alive" would be like. All he had to do was reach out to saidin. . . .

"nɑɾ əɡɛn," hi mʌɾɝd. hi ɡeɪzd ɔf ət ðə dɛd ɡɹoʊm, faɪv mɑnstʃɹəs ʃeɪps laɪɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. nɑt deɪnʒɝəs ɛnimɔɹ. "naʊ wi kən bi ɑn əɹ - "

"Not again," he muttered. He gazed off at the dead grolm, five monstrous shapes lying on the ground. Not dangerous anymore. "Now we can be on our - "

ə kɑfɪŋ bɑɹk, ɔl tu fəmɪljɝ, saʊndəd bɪɑn ðə dɛd ɡɹoʊm, bɪɑn ðə nɛks hɪl, ən ʌðɝz ænsɝɾ ɪt. stɪl mɔɹ keɪm, fɹəm ði ist, fɹəm ðə wɛst.

A coughing bark, all too familiar, sounded beyond the dead grolm, beyond the next hill, and others answered it. Still more came, from the east, from the west.

ɹænd hæf ɹeɪzd ɪz baʊ.

Rand half raised his bow.

"haʊ mɛni æɹoʊz juv lɛft?" səlin dɪmændəd. "kæn jə kɪl twɛnti ɡɹoʊm? θɝɾi? ə hʌnʒɹəd? wi mʌst ɡoʊ tə ðə pɔɹɾəl stoʊn."

"How many arrows do you have left?" Selene demanded. "Can you kill twenty grolm? Thirty? A hundred? We must go to the Portal Stone."

"ʃi ɪz ɹaɪt, ɹænd," lɔɪəl sɛd sloʊli. "ju də nɑɾ əv ɛni tʃɔɪs naʊ." hʊɹɪn wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ ɹænd æŋkʃəsli. ðə ɡɹoʊm kɔld, ə skɔɹ ə bɑɹks oʊvɝlæpɪŋ.

"She is right, Rand," Loial said slowly. "You do not have any choice now." Hurin was watching Rand anxiously. The grolm called, a score of barks overlapping.

"ðə stoʊn," ɹænd əɡɹid ɹɪlʌktənli. æŋɡɹəli hi θɹu hɪmsɛlf bæk ɪndə hɪz sæɾəl, slʌŋ ðə baʊ ɑn ɪz bæk. "lɛɾ əs tə ðɪs stoʊn, səlin."

"The Stone," Rand agreed reluctantly. Angrily he threw himself back into his saddle, slung the bow on his back. "Lead us to this Stone, Selene."

wɪð ə nɑd ʃi tɝn əɹ mɛɹ ən hild ɪt tə ə tʃɹɑt. ɹænd ən ði ʌðɝz fɑloʊd, ðeɪ iɡɝli, hi hoʊldɪŋ bæk. ðə bɑɹks ʌv ɡɹoʊm pɝsud ðɛm, hʌnʒɹədz ɪt simd. ɪt saʊndəɾ əz ɪf ðə ɡɹoʊm wɝ ɹeɪnʒd ɪn ə sɛmɪsɝkəl ɝaʊn ðɛm, kloʊzɪŋ ɪn fɹəm ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən bʌt ðə fɹʌnt.

With a nod she turned her mare and heeled it to a trot. Rand and the others followed, they eagerly, he holding back. The barks of grolm pursued them, hundreds it seemed. It sounded as if the grolm were ranged in a semicircle around them, closing in from every direction but the front.

swɪfli ən ʃʊɹli səlin lɛɾ əm θɹu ðə hɪlz. ðə læn ɹoʊz ɪn ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ ə maʊntənz, sloʊps stipənɪŋ soʊ ðə hɔɹsəz skɹæmbəld oʊvɝ wɑʃt-aʊt-lʊkɪŋ ɹɑki aʊtkɹɑps ən ðə spɑɹs, feɪɾəd-lʊkɪŋ bɹʌʃ ðət klʌŋ tə ðɛm. ðə weɪ bɪkeɪm hɑɹɾɝ, ðə læn slæntɪŋ mɔɹ ən mɔɹ ʌpwɝd.

Swiftly and surely Selene led them through the hills. The land rose in the beginning of mountains, slopes steepening so the horses scrambled over washed-out-looking rocky outcrops and the sparse, faded-looking brush that clung to them. The way became harder, the land slanting more and more upward.

wɝ nɑt gɑnə meɪk ɪt, ɹænd θɔt, ðə fɪfθ taɪm ɹɛd slɪpt ən slɪd bækwɝdz ɪn ə ʃaʊɝ ə stoʊn. lɔɪəl θɹu hɪz kɔɹɾɝstæf əsaɪd; ɪt wəd bi ʌv noʊ jus əɡɛnst ɡɹoʊm, ən ɪɾ oʊnli sloʊd hɪm. ði oʊɡiɝ hæd ɡɪvən ʌp ɹaɪɾɪŋ; hi juzd wʌn hæn tə hɔl hɪmsɛlf ʌp, ən pʊld ɪz tɔl hɔɹs bɪhaɪn ɪm wɪð ði ʌðɝ. ðə hɛɹi-fɛtlɑkt ænəməl meɪd hɛvi ɡoʊɪŋ, bʌɾ iziɝ ðən wɪð lɔɪəl ɑn ɪts bæk. ɡɹoʊm bɑɹk bɪhaɪn ðɛm, kloʊsɝ naʊ.

We're not going to make it, Rand thought, the fifth time Red slipped and slid backwards in a shower of stone. Loial threw his quarterstaff aside; it would be of no use against grolm, and it only slowed him. The Ogier had given up riding; he used one hand to haul himself up, and pulled his tall horse behind him with the other. The hairy-fetlocked animal made heavy going, but easier than with Loial on its back. Grolm barked behind them, closer now.

ðən səlin dʒɹu ɹeɪn ən pɔɪntəd tə ə hɑloʊ nɛsəl bɪloʊ ðɛm ɪn ðə ɡɹænət. ɪt wɑz ɔl ðɛɹ, ðə sɛvən waɪd, kʌlɝd stɛɹz ɝaʊn ə peɪl flɔɹ, ən ðə tɔl stoʊn kɑləm ɪn ðə mɪɾəl.

Then Selene drew rein and pointed to a hollow nestled below them in the granite. It was all there, the seven wide, colored stairs around a pale floor, and the tall stone column in the middle.

ʃi dɪsmaʊntɪɾ ən lɛɾ əɹ mɛɹ ɪndə ðə hɑloʊ, daʊn ðə stɛɹz tə ðə kɑləm. ɪt lumd oʊvɝ hɝ. ʃi tɝn tə lʊk bæk ʌp ət ɹænd ən ði ʌðɝz. ðə ɡɹoʊm ɡeɪv ðɛɹ ɡɹʌntɪŋ bɑɹks, skɔɹz ə ðɛm, laʊd. nɪɹ. "ðeɪ wɪl bi ɑn əs sun," ʃi sɛd. "ju mʌs juz ðə stoʊn, ɹænd. əɹ ɛls faɪn ə weɪ tə kɪl ɔl ðə ɡɹoʊm."

She dismounted and led her mare into the hollow, down the stairs to the column. It loomed over her. She turned to look back up at Rand and the others. The grolm gave their grunting barks, scores of them, loud. Near. "They will be on us soon," she said. "You must use the Stone, Rand. Or else find a way to kill all the grolm."

wɪð ə saɪ, ɹænd ɡɑt daʊn fɹəm ɪz sæɾəl ən lɛd ɹɛɾ ɪndə ðə hɑloʊ. lɔɪəl ən hʊɹɪn fɑloʊd heɪstəli. hi stɛɹɾ ət ðə sɪmbəl-kʌvɝd kɑləm, ðə pɔɹɾəl stoʊn, ənizəli. ʃi mʌs bi eɪbəl tə tʃænəl, ivən ɪf ʃi dʌznt noʊ ɪt, əɹ ɪt kʊdn əv bɹɔɾ əɹ hɪɹ. ðə paʊɝ dʌzn hɑɹm wɪmən. "ɪf ðɪs bɹɔt jə hɪɹ," hi bɪɡæn, bʌt ʃi ɪntɝʌptɪd hɪm.

With a sigh, Rand got down from his saddle and led Red into the hollow. Loial and Hurin followed hastily. He stared at the symbol-covered column, the Portal Stone, uneasily. She must be able to channel, even if she doesn't know it, or it couldn't have brought her here. The Power doesn't harm women. "If this brought you here," he began, but she interrupted him.

"aɪ noʊ wʌɾ ɪɾ ɪz," ʃi sɛd fɝmli, "bʌɾ aɪ də nɑt noʊ haʊ tə juz ɪt. jə mʌs də wʌt mʌs bi dʌn." ʃi tʃɹeɪst wʌn sɪmbəl, ə lɪɾəl lɑɹdʒɝ ðən ði ʌðɝz, wɪð ə fɪŋɡɝ. ə tʃɹaɪæŋɡəl stændɪŋ ɑn ɪts pɔɪn ɪnsaɪɾ ə sɝkəl. "ðɪs stænz fəɹ ðə tʃɹu wɝld, əɹ wɝld. aɪ bɪliv ɪɾəl hɛlp ɪf jə hoʊld ɪɾ ɪn jəɹ maɪnd waɪl ju. . . ." ʃi spɹɛɾ əɹ hænz əz ɪf ənʃʊɹ ɪɡzækli wʌɾ ɪt wɑz i wɑz səpoʊz tə du.

"I know what it is," she said firmly, "but I do not know how to use it. You must do what must be done." She traced one symbol, a little larger than the others, with a finger. A triangle standing on its point inside a circle. "This stands for the true world, our world. I believe it will help if you hold it in your mind while you. . . ." She spread her hands as if unsure exactly what it was he was supposed to do.

"ʌ . . . maɪ lɔɹd?" hʊɹɪn sɛd dɪfəɾəntli. "ðɛɹ ɪzən mʌtʃ taɪm." hi ɡlænst oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ət ðə ɹɪm ə ðə hɑloʊ. ðə bɑɹkɪŋ wɑz laʊɾɝ. "ðoʊz θɪŋz wɪl bi hɪɹ ɪn mɪnəts, naʊ." lɔɪəl nɑɾəd.

"Uh . . . my Lord?" Hurin said diffidently. "There isn't much time." He glanced over his shoulder at the rim of the hollow. The barking was louder. "Those things will be here in minutes, now." Loial nodded.

dʒɹɔɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ, ɹænd pʊɾ ɪz hæn ɑn ðə sɪmbəl səlin hæd pɔɪntəɾ aʊt. hi lʊkt əɾ əɹ tə si ɪf i wɑz duɪŋ ɪt ɹaɪt, bʌt ʃi mɪɹli wɑtʃt, nɑɾ ivən ðə slaɪɾəst fɹaʊn ʌv wɝi ɹɪŋkəlɪŋ əɹ peɪl fɔɹhɛd. ʃiz kɑnfəɾənt jə kən seɪv hɝ. juv tə. ðə sɛn ə hɝ fɪld ɪz nɑstʃɹəlz.

Drawing a deep breath, Rand put his hand on the symbol Selene had pointed out. He looked at her to see if he was doing it right, but she merely watched, not even the slightest frown of worry wrinkling her pale forehead. She's confident you can save her. You have to. The scent of her filled his nostrils.

"ʌ . . . maɪ lɔɹd?"

"Uh . . . my Lord?"

ɹænd swɑloʊd, ən sɔt ðə vɔɪd. ɪt keɪm izəli, spɹɪŋɪŋ ʌp ɝaʊn ɪm wɪθaʊɾ ɛfɝt. ɛmptinəs. ɛmptinəs ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə laɪt, weɪvɝɪŋ ɪn ə weɪ ðət tɝn ɪz stʌmək. ɛmptinəs ɪksɛp fəɹ seɪɾɪn. bʌɾ ivən ðə kwizinəs wɑz dɪstənt. hi wɑz wʌn wɪð ðə pɔɹɾəl stoʊn. ðə kɑləm fɛl smuð ən slaɪtli ɔɪli ʌndɝ ɪz hænd, bʌt ðə tʃɹaɪæŋɡəl-ænd-sɝkəl simd wɔɹm əɡɛns ðə bɹæn ɑn ɪz pɑm. hæv tə ɡɛɾ əm tə seɪfti. hæv tə ɡɛɾ əm hoʊm. ðə laɪt dʒɹɪftəd təwɔɹd hɪm, ɪt simd, sɝaʊndəd hɪm, ən i . . . ɛmbɹeɪst . . . ɪt.

Rand swallowed, and sought the void. It came easily, springing up around him without effort. Emptiness. Emptiness except for the light, wavering in a way that turned his stomach. Emptiness except for saidin. But even the queasiness was distant. He was one with the Portal Stone. The column felt smooth and slightly oily under his hand, but the triangle-and-circle seemed warm against the brand on his palm. Have to get them to safety. Have to get them home. The light drifted toward him, it seemed, surrounded him, and he . . . embraced . . . it.

laɪt fɪl hɪm. hit fɪl hɪm. hi kəd si ðə stoʊn, si ði ʌðɝz wɑtʃɪŋ ɪm - lɔɪəl ən hʊɹɪn æŋkʃəsli, səlin ʃoʊɪŋ noʊ daʊt ðəɾ i kəd seɪv əɹ - bʌt ðeɪ maɪɾ əz wɛl nɑɾ əv bɪn ðɛɹ. ðə laɪt wɑz ɔl. ðə hiɾ ən ðə laɪt, sʌfjuzɪŋ ɪz lɪmz laɪk wɔɾɝ sɪŋkɪŋ ɪndə dʒɹaɪ sænd, fɪlɪŋ hɪm. ðə sɪmbəl bɝn əɡɛnst ɪz flɛʃ. hi tʃɹaɪd tə sʌk ɪɾ ɔl ɪn, ɔl ðə hit, ɔl ðə laɪt. ɔl. ðə sɪmbəl. . . .

Light filled him. Heat filled him. He could see the Stone, see the others watching him - Loial and Hurin anxiously, Selene showing no doubt that he could save her - but they might as well not have been there. The light was all. The heat and the light, suffusing his limbs like water sinking into dry sand, filling him. The symbol burned against his flesh. He tried to suck it all in, all the heat, all the light. All. The symbol. . . .

sʌɾənli, əz ɪf ðə sʌn hæd ɡɔn aʊt fəɹ ðə blɪŋk ʌv ən aɪ, ðə wɝl flɪkɝd. ən əɡɛn. ðə sɪmbəl wɑz ə laɪv koʊl ʌndɝ ɪz hænd; hi dʒɹæŋk ɪn ðə laɪt. ðə wɝl flɪkɝd. flɪkɝd. ɪt meɪɾ ɪm sɪk, ðət laɪt; ɪt wɑz wɔɾɝ tə ə mæn daɪɪŋ ə θɝst. flɪkɝ. hi sʌkt əɾ ɪt. ɪt meɪɾ ɪm wɑnə vɑmət; hi wɑntəɾ ɪɾ ɔl. flɪkɝ. ðə tʃɹaɪæŋɡəl-ænd-sɝkəl sɪɹd hɪm; hi kəd fil ɪt tʃæɹɪŋ ɪz hænd. flɪkɝ. hi wɑntəɾ ɪɾ ɔl! hi skɹimd, haʊlɪŋ wɪð peɪn, haʊlɪŋ wɪð wɑntɪŋ.

Suddenly, as if the sun had gone out for the blink of an eye, the world flickered. And again. The symbol was a live coal under his hand; he drank in the light. The world flickered. Flickered. It made him sick, that light; it was water to a man dying of thirst. Flicker. He sucked at it. It made him want to vomit; he wanted it all. Flicker. The triangle-and-circle seared him; he could feel it charring his hand. Flicker. He wanted it all! He screamed, howling with pain, howling with wanting.

flɪkɝ . . . flɪkɝ . . . flɪkɝflɪkɝflɪkɝ. . . .

Flicker . . . flicker . . . flickerflickerflicker. . . .

hænz pʊld ət hɪm; hi wɑz oʊnli veɪɡli əwɛɹ ə ðɛm. hi stæɡɝd bæk; ðə vɔɪd wɑz slɪpɪŋ əweɪ, ðə laɪt, ən ðə sɪknəs ðət twɪstəɾ ət hɪm. ðə laɪt. hi wɑtʃt ɪt ɡoʊ ɹɪɡɹɛtfəli. laɪt, ðæts kɹeɪzi tə wɑn ɪt. bʌɾ aɪ wɑz soʊ fʊl ʌv ɪt! aɪ wɑz soʊ. . . . deɪzd, hi stɛɹɾ ət səlin. ɪt wɑz ʃi hu hɛld ɪz ʃoʊldɝz, stɛɹd wʌndɝɪŋli ɪndə hɪz aɪz. hi ɹeɪzd ɪz hæn ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪz feɪs. ðə hɛɹən bɹænd wɑz ðɛɹ, bʌt nʌθɪŋ ɛls. noʊ tʃɹaɪæŋɡəl-ænd-sɝkəl bɝn ɪndə hɪz flɛʃ.

Hands pulled at him; he was only vaguely aware of them. He staggered back; the void was slipping away, the light, and the sickness that twisted at him. The light. He watched it go regretfully. Light, that's crazy to want it. But I was so full of it! I was so. . . . Dazed, he stared at Selene. It was she who held his shoulders, stared wonderingly into his eyes. He raised his hand in front of his face. The heron brand was there, but nothing else. No triangle-and-circle burned into his flesh.

"ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl," səlin sɛd sloʊli. ʃi ɡlænst ət lɔɪəl ən hʊɹɪn. ði oʊɡiɝ lʊk stʌnd, hɪz aɪz əz bɪɡ əz pleɪts; ðə snɪfɝ wɑz skwɑɾɪŋ wɪð wʌn hæn ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, əz ɪf ənʃʊɹ i kəd səpɔɹt hɪmsɛlf ɛls. "ɔl ʌv əs hɪɹ, ən ɔl ʌv əɹ hɔɹsəz. ən jə də nɑɾ ivən noʊ wʌt jə dɪd. ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl."

"Remarkable," Selene said slowly. She glanced at Loial and Hurin. The Ogier looked stunned, his eyes as big as plates; the sniffer was squatting with one hand on the ground, as if unsure he could support himself else. "All of us here, and all of our horses. And you do not even know what you did. Remarkable."

"ɑɹ wi . . . ?" ɹænd bɪɡæn hɔɹsli, ən hæd tə stɑp tə swɑloʊ.

"Are we . . . ?" Rand began hoarsely, and had to stop to swallow.

"lʊk ɝaʊn ju," səlin sɛd. "juv bɹɔɾ əs hoʊm." ʃi ɡeɪv ə sʌɾən læf. "ju bɹɔɾ ɔl ʌv əs hoʊm."

"Look around you," Selene said. "You've brought us home." She gave a sudden laugh. "You brought all of us home."

fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm ɹænd bɪkeɪm əwɛɹ ə hɪz sɝaʊndɪŋz əɡɛn. ðə hɑloʊ sɝaʊndəɾ əm wɪθaʊɾ ɛni stɛɹz, ðoʊ hɪɹ ən ðəɹ leɪ ə səspɪʃəsli smuð pis ə stoʊn, kʌlɝd ɹɛd, əɹ blu. ðə kɑləm leɪ əɡɛns ðə maʊntənsaɪd, hæf bɛɹiɾ ɪn ðə lus ɹɑk ʌv ə fɔl. ðə sɪmbəlz wɝ ənklɪɹ, hɪɹ; wɪn ən wɔɾɝ hæd wɝk lɔŋ ɑn ðɛm. ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ lʊkt ɹil. ðə kʌlɝz wɝ sɑləd, ðə ɡɹænəɾ ə stʃɹɔŋ ɡɹeɪ, ðə bɹʌʃ ɡɹin ən bɹaʊn. æftɝ ðəɾ ʌðɝ pleɪs, ɪt simd ɔlmoʊs tu vɪvəd.

For the first time Rand became aware of his surroundings again. The hollow surrounded them without any stairs, though here and there lay a suspiciously smooth piece of stone, colored red, or blue. The column lay against the mountainside, half buried in the loose rock of a fall. The symbols were unclear, here; wind and water had worked long on them. And everything looked real. The colors were solid, the granite a strong gray, the brush green and brown. After that other place, it seemed almost too vivid.

"hoʊm," ɹænd bɹiðd, ən ðən i wɑz læfɪŋ, tu. "wɝ hoʊm." lɔɪəlz læftɝ saʊndəd laɪk ə bʊl bɛloʊɪŋ. hʊɹɪn dænst ə keɪpɝ.

"Home," Rand breathed, and then he was laughing, too. "We're home." Loial's laughter sounded like a bull bellowing. Hurin danced a caper.

"ju dɪɾ ɪt," səlin sɛd, linɪŋ kloʊsɝ, əntɪl əɹ feɪs fɪld ɹændz aɪz. "aɪ nu ðət jə kʊd."

"You did it," Selene said, leaning closer, until her face filled Rand's eyes. "I knew that you could."

ɹændz læftɝ daɪd. "aɪ - aɪ səpoʊz aɪ dɪd." hi ɡlænst ət ðə fɔlən pɔɹɾəl stoʊn ən mænədʒd ə wik læf. "aɪ wɪʃ aɪ nu wʌɾ ɪt wɑz aɪ dɪd, ðoʊ."

Rand's laughter died. "I - I suppose I did." He glanced at the fallen Portal Stone and managed a weak laugh. "I wish I knew what it was I did, though."

səlin lʊk dip ɪndə hɪz aɪz. "pɝhæps wʌn deɪ jəl noʊ," ʃi sɛd sɔfli. "ju ɑɹ ʃʊɹli dɛstɪn fəɹ ɡɹeɪt θɪŋz."

Selene looked deep into his eyes. "Perhaps one day you will know," she said softly. "You are surely destined for great things."

hɝ aɪz simd əz dɑɹk ən dip əz naɪt, əz sɑft əz vɛlvət. hɝ maʊθ. . . . ɪf aɪ kɪs hɝ. . . . hi blɪŋkt ən stɛp bæk hɝidli, klɪɹɪŋ ɪz θɹoʊt. "səlin, pliz doʊn tɛl ɛniwʌn əbaʊt ðɪs. əbaʊt ðə pɔɹɾəl stoʊn, ən mi. aɪ doʊn ʌndɝstæn ɪt, ən niðɝ wɪl ɛnibəɾi ɛls. jə noʊ haʊ pipəl ɑɹ əbaʊt θɪŋz ðeɪ doʊn ʌndɝstænd."

Her eyes seemed as dark and deep as night, as soft as velvet. Her mouth. . . . If I kissed her. . . . He blinked and stepped back hurriedly, clearing his throat. "Selene, please don't tell anyone about this. About the Portal Stone, and me. I don't understand it, and neither will anybody else. You know how people are about things they don't understand."

hɝ feɪs wɔɹ noʊ ɪkspɹɛʃən əɾ ɔl. sʌɾənli hi wɪʃt vɛɹi mʌtʃ ðət mæt ən pɛɹɪn wɝ ðɛɹ. pɛɹɪn nu haʊ tə tɔk tə ɡɝlz, ən mæt kəd laɪ wɪð ə stʃɹeɪt feɪs. hi kəd mænədʒ niðɝ vɛɹi wɛl.

Her face wore no expression at all. Suddenly he wished very much that Mat and Perrin were there. Perrin knew how to talk to girls, and Mat could lie with a straight face. He could manage neither very well.

sʌɾənli səlin smaɪld, ən dʒɹɑpt ə hæf-mɑkɪŋ kɝtsi. "aɪ wɪl kip jəɹ sikɹət, maɪ lɔɹd ɹænd ælθɹ."

Suddenly Selene smiled, and dropped a half-mocking curtsy. "I will keep your secret, my Lord Rand al'Thor."

ɹænd ɡlænst ət hɝ, ən klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊɾ əɡɛn. ɪz ʃi æŋɡɹi wɪð mi? ʃid sɝɾənli bi æŋɡɹi ɪf aɪ hæd tʃɹaɪd tə kɪs hɝ. aɪ θɪŋk. hi wɪʃt ʃi wəd nɑt lʊk əɾ ɪm əz ʃi wɑz, əz ɪf ʃi nu wʌɾ i wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ. "hʊɹɪn, ɪz ðəɹ ɛni tʃæns ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz juz ðɪs stoʊn bɪfɔɹ ʌs?"

Rand glanced at her, and cleared his throat again. Is she angry with me? She'd certainly be angry if I had tried to kiss her. I think. He wished she would not look at him as she was, as if she knew what he was thinking. "Hurin, is there any chance the Darkfriends used this Stone before us?"

ðə snɪfɝ ʃʊk ɪz hɛd ɹufəli. "ðeɪ wɝ æŋɡlɪŋ tə ðə wɛst ə hɪɹ, lɔɹd ɹænd. ənlɛs ðiz pɔɹɾəl stoʊn θɪŋz ɑɹ mɔɹ kɑmən ðən aɪv sin, aɪd seɪ ðəɹ stɪl ɪn ðəɾ ʌðɝ wɝld. bʌɾ ɪt wʊdn teɪk mi ən aʊɝ tə tʃɛk ɪt. ðə lænz ðə seɪm hɪɹ əz ðɛɹ. aɪ kəd faɪn ðə pleɪs hɪɹ wɛɹ aɪ lɔs ðə tʃɹeɪl ðɛɹ, ɪf jə si wʌɾ aɪ min, ən si ɪf ðeɪv ɔlɹɛɾi ɡɔn baɪ."

The sniffer shook his head ruefully. "They were angling to the west of here, Lord Rand. Unless these Portal Stone things are more common than I've seen, I'd say they're still in that other world. But it wouldn't take me an hour to check it. The land's the same here as there. I could find the place here where I lost the trail there, if you see what I mean, and see if they've already gone by."

ɹænd ɡlænst ət ðə skaɪ. ðə sʌn - ə wʌndɝfəli stʃɹɔŋ sʌn, nɑt peɪl əɾ ɔl - sæt loʊ tə ðə wɛst, stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ ðɛɹ ʃædoʊz aʊɾ əkɹɔs ðə hɑloʊ. ənʌðɝ aʊɝ wəd bɹɪŋ fʊl twaɪlaɪt. "ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ," hi sɛd. "bʌɾ aɪ fɪɹ wiv lɔs ðɛm." wi kæn luz ðət dæɡɝ! wi kænt! "səlin, ɪf ðæts ðə keɪs, ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ wɪl teɪk jə ɑn tə jəɹ hoʊm. ɪz ɪɾ ɪn ðə sɪɾi ʌv kɛɹhin ɪtsɛlf, əɹ . . . ?"

Rand glanced at the sky. The sun - a wonderfully strong sun, not pale at all - sat low to the west, stretching their shadows out across the hollow. Another hour would bring full twilight. "In the morning," he said. "But I fear we've lost them." We can't lose that dagger! We can't! "Selene, if that's the case, in the morning we will take you on to your home. Is it in the city of Cairhien itself, or . . . ?"

"ju meɪ nɑɾ əv lɔs ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ jɛt," səlin sɛd sloʊli. "æz jə noʊ, aɪ də noʊ ə fju θɪŋz əbaʊt ðoʊz wɝlz."

"You may not have lost the Horn of Valere yet," Selene said slowly. "As you know, I do know a few things about those worlds."

"mɪɹɝz ə ðə wil," lɔɪəl sɛd.

"Mirrors of the Wheel," Loial said.

ʃi ɡeɪv ɪm ə lʊk, ðən nɑɾəd. "jɛs. ɪɡzækli. ðoʊz wɝlz tʃɹuli ɑɹ mɪɹɝz ɪn ə weɪ, ɪspɛʃli ðə wʌnz wɛɹ ðəɹ ɑɹ noʊ pipəl. səm ə ðɛm ɹəflɛkt oʊnli ɡɹeɪɾ ɪvɛns ɪn ðə tʃɹu wɝld, bʌt səm əv ə ʃædoʊ ʌv ðət ɹəflɛkʃən ivən bɪfɔɹ ði ɪvɛn əkɝz. ðə pæsədʒ ə ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ wəd sɝɾənli bi ə ɡɹeɪɾ ɪvɛnt. ɹɪflɛkʃənz ʌv wʌt wɪl bi ɑɹ feɪntɝ ðən ɹɪflɛkʃənz ʌv wʌɾ ɪz əɹ wʌt wɑz, dʒʌst əz hʊɹɪn sɛz ðə tʃɹeɪl i fɑloʊd wɑz feɪnt."

She gave him a look, then nodded. "Yes. Exactly. Those worlds truly are mirrors in a way, especially the ones where there are no people. Some of them reflect only great events in the true world, but some have a shadow of that reflection even before the event occurs. The passage of the Horn of Valere would certainly be a great event. Reflections of what will be are fainter than reflections of what is or what was, just as Hurin says the trail he followed was faint."

hʊɹɪn blɪŋkt ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli. "ju min tə seɪ, maɪ leɪɾi, aɪv bɪn smɛlɪŋ wɛɹ ðoʊz dɑɹkfɹɛnz ɑɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə bi? ðə laɪt hɛlp mi, aɪ wʊdn laɪk ðæt. ɪts bæɾ ɪnʌf smɛlɪŋ wɛɹ vaɪələns əz bɪn, wɪθaʊt smɛlɪŋ wɛɹ ɪɾəl bi, tu. ðəɹ kæn bi mɛni spɑts wɛɹ ðəɹ woʊn bi səm kaɪndə vaɪələns, səm taɪm. ɪt wəd dʒɹaɪv mi kɹeɪzi, laɪk əz nɑt. ðət pleɪs wi dʒʌs lɛf nɪɹli dɪd. aɪ kəd smɛl ɪɾ ɔl ðə taɪm, ðɛɹ, kɪlɪŋ ən hɝɾɪŋ, ən ðə vaɪləst ivəl jə kəd θɪŋk ʌv. aɪ kəɾ ivən smɛl ɪɾ ɑn ʌs. ɑn ɔl ʌv ʌs. ivən ɑn ju, maɪ leɪɾi, ɪf jəl fɝɡɪv mi fəɹ seɪɪŋ soʊ. ɪt wɑz dʒʌs ðət pleɪs, twɪstɪŋ mi ðə weɪ ɪt twɪstəd jəɹ aɪ." hi ɡeɪv hɪmsɛlf ə ʃeɪk. "aɪm ɡlæd wɝ aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ. aɪ kænt ɡɛɾ ɪɾ aʊɾ ə maɪ nɑstʃɹəlz jɛt, ɔl ðə weɪ."

Hurin blinked incredulously. "You mean to say, my Lady, I've been smelling where those Darkfriends are going to be? The Light help me, I wouldn't like that. It's bad enough smelling where violence has been, without smelling where it will be, too. There can't be many spots where there won't be some kind of violence, some time. It would drive me crazy, like as not. That place we just left nearly did. I could smell it all the time, there, killing and hurting, and the vilest evil you could think of. I could even smell it on us. On all of us. Even on you, my Lady, if you'll forgive me for saying so. It was just that place, twisting me the way it twisted your eye." He gave himself a shake. "I'm glad we're out of there. I can't get it out of my nostrils yet, all the way."

ɹænd ɹʌbd æbsənli ət ðə bɹæn ɑn ɪz pɑm. "wʌt dʒju θɪŋk, lɔɪəl? kəd wi ɹɪli bi əhɛɾ ə feɪnz dɑɹkfɹɛnz?"

Rand rubbed absently at the brand on his palm. "What do you think, Loial? Could we really be ahead of Fain's Darkfriends?"

ði oʊɡiɝ ʃɹʌɡd, fɹaʊnɪŋ. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ, ɹænd. aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɛniθɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɛni ʌv ðɪs. aɪ θɪŋk wəɹ bæk ɪn əɹ wɝld. aɪ θɪŋk wəɹ ɪn kɪnsleɪɝz dæɡɝ. bɪɑn ðæt. . . ." hi ʃɹʌɡd əɡɛn.

The Ogier shrugged, frowning. "I don't know, Rand. I don't know anything about any of this. I think we are back in our world. I think we are in Kinslayer's Dagger. Beyond that. . . ." He shrugged again.

"wi ʃəd bi siɪŋ jə hoʊm, səlin," ɹænd sɛd. "jɔɹ pipəl wɪl bi wɝiɾ əbaʊt ju."

"We should be seeing you home, Selene," Rand said. "Your people will be worried about you."

"ə fju deɪz wɪl si ɪf aɪm ɹaɪt," ʃi sɛɾ ɪmpeɪʃənli. "hʊɹɪn kən faɪnd wɛɹ i lɛf ðə tʃɹeɪl; hi sɛd soʊ. wi kən wɑtʃ oʊvɝ ɪt. ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ kænɑt bi mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ ɹitʃɪŋ hɪɹ. ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ, ɹænd. θɪŋk ʌv ɪt. ðə mæn u saʊnz ðə hɔɹn wɪl lɪv ɪn lɛdʒən fɝɛvɝ."

"A few days will see if I'm right," she said impatiently. "Hurin can find where he left the trail; he said so. We can watch over it. The Horn of Valere cannot be much longer reaching here. The Horn of Valere, Rand. Think of it. The man who sounds the Horn will live in legend forever."

"aɪ doʊnt wɑn ɛniθɪŋ tə də wɪð lɛdʒənz," hi sɛd ʃɑɹpli. bʌɾ ɪf ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz ɡɛt baɪ ju. . . . wʌɾ ɪf ɪŋtʃɹ lɔs ðɛm? ðən ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz əv ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ fɝɛvɝ, ən mæt daɪz. "ɔl ɹaɪt, ə fju deɪz. ət ðə wɝst, wɪl pɹɑbli miɾ ɪŋtʃɹ ən ði ʌðɝz. aɪ kæn ɪmædʒən ðeɪv stɑpt əɹ tɝn bæk dʒʌs kəz wi . . . wɛn əweɪ."

"I don't want anything to do with legends," he said sharply. But if the Darkfriends get by you. . . . What if Ingtar lost them? Then the Darkfriends have the Horn of Valere forever, and Mat dies. "All right, a few days. At the worst, we will probably meet Ingtar and the others. I can't imagine they've stopped or turned back just because we . . . went away."

"ə waɪz dɪsɪʒən, ɹænd," səlin sɛd, "ænd wɛl θɔɾ aʊt." ʃi tʌtʃt ɪz ɑɹm ən smaɪld, ən i faʊn hɪmsɛlf əɡɛn θɪŋkɪŋ ə kɪsɪŋ hɝ.

"A wise decision, Rand," Selene said, "and well thought out." She touched his arm and smiled, and he found himself again thinking of kissing her.

"ʌ . . . wi nid tə bi kloʊsɝ tə wɛɹ ðəl kʌm. ɪf ðeɪ də kʌm. hʊɹɪn, kən jə faɪn əs ə kæmp bɪfɔɹ dɑɹk, sʌmwɛɹ wi kən wɑtʃ ðə pleɪs wɛɹ jə lɔs ðə tʃɹeɪl?" hi ɡlænst ət ðə pɔɹɾəl stoʊn ən θɔɾ əbaʊt slipɪŋ nɪɹ ɪt, θɔɾ ə ðə weɪ ðə vɔɪd hæd kɹɛpt ʌp ɑn ɪm ɪn slip ðə læs taɪm, ən ðə laɪɾ ɪn ðə vɔɪd. "sʌmwɛɹ wɛl əweɪ fɹəm hɪɹ."

"Uh . . . we need to be closer to where they'll come. If they do come. Hurin, can you find us a camp before dark, somewhere we can watch the place where you lost the trail?" He glanced at the Portal Stone and thought about sleeping near it, thought of the way the void had crept up on him in sleep the last time, and the light in the void. "Somewhere well away from here."

"liv ɪɾ ɪn maɪ hænz, lɔɹd ɹænd." ðə snɪfɝ skɹæmbəl tə hɪz sæɾəl. "aɪ vaʊ, əl nɛvɝ slip əɡɛn wɪθaʊt fɝst aɪ si wʌt kaɪndə stoʊn ðəɹ ɪz nɪɹbaɪ."

"Leave it in my hands, Lord Rand." The sniffer scrambled to his saddle. "I vow, I'll never sleep again without first I see what kind of stone there is nearby."

əz ɹænd ɹoʊd ɹɛɾ ʌp aʊɾ ə ðə hɑloʊ, hi faʊn hɪmsɛlf wɑtʃɪŋ səlin mɔɹ ðən i dɪd hʊɹɪn. ʃi sim soʊ kul ən sɛlf-pəzɛst, noʊ oʊldɝ ðən hi, jɛt kwinli, bʌt wən ʃi smaɪld ət hɪm, əz ʃi dɪd dʒʌs ðɛn. . . . ɛɡwin wʊdn əv sɛɾ aɪ wɑz waɪz. ɛɡwin wʊɾə kɔl mi ə wʊlhɛd. ɪɹɪɾəbli, hi hild ɹɛdz flæŋks.

As Rand rode Red up out of the hollow, he found himself watching Selene more than he did Hurin. She seemed so cool and self-possessed, no older than he, yet queenly, but when she smiled at him, as she did just then. . . . Egwene wouldn't have said I was wise. Egwene would have called me a woolhead. Irritably, he heeled Red's flanks.


tʃæptɝ eɪtin


CHAPTER 18

tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ


To the White Tower

ɛɡwin bælənst ɑn ðə hilɪŋ dɛk əz ðə ɹɪvɝ kwin spɛd daʊn ðə waɪɾ ɛɹɪnɪn ʌndɝ klaʊd-dɑɹk skaɪz, seɪlz fʊl-bɛlid, waɪt fleɪm bænɝ wɪpɪŋ fjʊɹiəsli ət ðə meɪnməst. ðə wɪn hæd ɹɪzən əz sun əz ðə læst ə ðɛm wɑz əbɔɹd ðə ʃɪps, bæk ɪn mɛɾoʊ, ən ɪt hæd nɑt feɪld əɹ flæɡd fəɹ ən ɪnstən sɪns, deɪ əɹ naɪt. ðə ɹɪvɝ hæd bɪɡʌn tə ɹeɪs ɪn flʌd, əz ɪt stɪl dɪd, slæpɪŋ ðə ʃɪps əbaʊt waɪl ɪt dʒɹoʊv əm ɔnwɝd. wɪn ən ɹɪvɝ hæd nɑt sloʊd, ən niðɝ hæd ðə ʃɪps, ɔl klʌstɝd təɡɛðɝ. ðə ɹɪvɝ kwin lɛd, oʊnli ɹaɪt fəɹ ðə vɛsəl ðət kæɹid ði æmɪɝlɪn sit.

Egwene balanced on the heeling deck as the River Queen sped down the wide Erinin under cloud-dark skies, sails full-bellied, White Flame banner whipping furiously at the mainmast. The wind had risen as soon as the last of them was aboard the ships, back in Medo, and it had not failed or flagged for an instant since, day or night. The river had begun to race in flood, as it still did, slapping the ships about while it drove them onward. Wind and river had not slowed, and neither had the ships, all clustered together. The River Queen led, only right for the vessel that carried the Amyrlin Seat.

ðə hɛlmzmæn hɛld ɪz tɪlɝ ɡɹɪmli, fit plæntəɾ ən spɹɛd, ən seɪlɝz pæɾəd bɛɹfʊɾ ət ðɛɹ wɝk, ɪntɛn ɑn wʌt ðeɪ dɪd; wən ðeɪ ɡlænst ət ðə skaɪ əɹ ðə ɹɪvɝ, ðeɪ tɔɹ ðɛɹ aɪz əweɪ wɪð loʊ mʌɾɝz. ə vɪlədʒ wɑz dʒʌs feɪɾɪŋ fɹəm vju bɪhaɪnd, ən ə bɔɪ ɹeɪst əlɔŋ ðə bæŋk; hi hæd kɛpt ʌp wɪð ðə ʃɪps fəɹ ə ʃɔɹt dɪstəns, bʌt naʊ ðeɪ wɝ livɪŋ ɪm bɪhaɪnd. wən i vænɪʃt, ɛɡwin meɪɾ əɹ weɪ bɪloʊ.

The helmsman held his tiller grimly, feet planted and spread, and sailors padded barefoot at their work, intent on what they did; when they glanced at the sky or the river, they tore their eyes away with low mutters. A village was just fading from view behind, and a boy raced along the bank; he had kept up with the ships for a short distance, but now they were leaving him behind. When he vanished, Egwene made her way below.

ɪn ðə smɔl kæbən ðeɪ ʃɛɹd, nɪneɪiv ɡlɛɹɾ ʌp əɾ əɹ fɹəm əɹ nɛɹoʊ bɛd. "ðeɪ seɪ wɪl ɹitʃ tɑɹ vəlɑn tədeɪ. ðə laɪt hɛlp mi, bʌɾ əl bi ɡlæd tə pʊt fʊɾ ɑn læn əɡɛn ivən ɪf ɪts ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn." ðə ʃɪp lɝtʃt wɪð wɪn ən kɝənt, ən nɪneɪiv swɑloʊd. "aɪl nɛvɝ stɛp ɑn ə boʊɾ əɡɛn," ʃi sɛd bɹɛθləsli.

In the small cabin they shared, Nynaeve glared up at her from her narrow bed. "They say we'll reach Tar Valon today. The Light help me, but I'll be glad to put foot on land again even if it is in Tar Valon." The ship lurched with wind and current, and Nynaeve swallowed. "I'll never step on a boat again," she said breathlessly.

ɛɡwin ʃʊk ðə ɹɪvɝ spɹeɪ aʊɾ ə hɝ kloʊk ən hʌŋ ɪɾ ɑn ə pɛɡ baɪ ðə dɔɹ. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə bɪɡ kæbən - ðəɹ wɝ noʊ bɪɡ kæbənz ɑn ðə ʃɪp, ɪt simd, nɑɾ ivən ðə wʌn ði æmɪɝlɪn hæd teɪkən oʊvɝ fɹəm ðə kæptən, ðoʊ ðət wɑz lɑɹdʒɝ ðən ðə ɹɛst. wɪð ɪts tu bɛdz bɪlt ɪndə ðə wɔlz, ʃɛlvz bɪniθ əm ən kæbənəts əbʌv, ɛvɹiθɪŋ leɪ kloʊs tə hænd.

Egwene shook the river spray out of her cloak and hung it on a peg by the door. It was not a big cabin - there were no big cabins on the ship, it seemed, not even the one the Amyrlin had taken over from the captain, though that was larger than the rest. With its two beds built into the walls, shelves beneath them and cabinets above, everything lay close to hand.

ɪksɛp fəɹ kipɪŋ əɹ bæləns, ðə muvməns ə ðə ʃɪp dɪd nɑt bɑðɝ əɹ ðə weɪ ðeɪ dɪd nɪneɪiv; ʃi hæd ɡɪvən ʌp ɔfɝɪŋ nɪneɪiv fuɾ æftɝ ðə θɝd taɪm ðə wɪzdəm θɹu ðə boʊl ət hɝ. "aɪm wɝiɾ əbaʊt ɹænd," ʃi sɛd.

Except for keeping her balance, the movements of the ship did not bother her the way they did Nynaeve; she had given up offering Nynaeve food after the third time the Wisdom threw the bowl at her. "I'm worried about Rand," she said.

"aɪm wɝiɾ əbaʊɾ ɔl ə ðɛm," nɪneɪiv ɹɪplaɪd dʌli. æftɝ ə moʊmənt, ʃi sɛd, "ənʌðɝ dʒɹim læs naɪt? ðə weɪ juv bɪn stɛɹɪŋ ət nʌθɪŋ sɪns jə ɡɑɾ ʌp. . . ."

"I'm worried about all of them," Nynaeve replied dully. After a moment, she said, "Another dream last night? The way you've been staring at nothing since you got up. . . ."

ɛɡwin nɑɾəd. ʃi hæd nɛvɝ bɪn vɛɹi ɡʊɾ ət kipɪŋ θɪŋz fɹəm nɪneɪiv, ən ʃi hæd nɑt tʃɹaɪd wɪð ðə dʒɹimz. nɪneɪiv hæd tʃɹaɪd tə doʊs əɹ ət fɝst, əntɪl ʃi hɝd wʌn ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑz ɪntʃɹəstəd; ðən ʃi bɪɡæn tə bɪliv. "ɪt wɑz laɪk ði ʌðɝz. dɪfɹənt, bʌt ðə seɪm. ɹænd ɪz ɪn səm kaɪndə deɪnʒɝ. aɪ noʊ ɪt. ən ɪts ɡɛɾɪŋ wɝs. hiz dʌn sʌmθɪŋ, əɹ hiz gɑnə də sʌmθɪŋ, ðət pʊts ɪm ɪn. . . ." ʃi dʒɹɑp daʊn ɑn əɹ bɛɾ ən lin təwɔɹd ði ʌðɝ wʊmən. "aɪ dʒʌst wɪʃ aɪ kəd meɪk səm sɛns ʌv ɪt."

Egwene nodded. She had never been very good at keeping things from Nynaeve, and she had not tried with the dreams. Nynaeve had tried to dose her at first, until she heard one of the Aes Sedai was interested; then she began to believe. "It was like the others. Different, but the same. Rand is in some kind of danger. I know it. And it is getting worse. He's done something, or he's going to do something, that puts him in. . . ." She dropped down on her bed and leaned toward the other woman. "I just wish I could make some sense of it."

"tʃænəlɪŋ?" nɪneɪiv sɛd sɔfli.

"Channeling?" Nynaeve said softly.

dɪspaɪt hɝsɛlf, ɛɡwin lʊkt ɝaʊn tə si ɪf ɛniwʌn wɑz ðəɹ tə hɪɹ. ðeɪ wɝ əloʊn, wɪð ðə dɔɹ kloʊzd, bʌt stɪl ʃi spoʊk dʒʌst əz sɔfli. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ. meɪbi." ðəɹ wɑz noʊ tɛlɪŋ wʌɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd də - ʃi hæd sin ɪnʌf ɔlɹɛɾi tə meɪk əɹ bɪliv ɛvɹi stɔɹi ʌv ðɛɹ paʊɝz - ən ʃi wəd nɑt ɹɪsk ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ. aɪ woʊn ɹɪsk ɹænd. ɪf aɪ dɪd ɹaɪt, aɪd tɛl ðɛm, bʌt mɔɪɹeɪn noʊz, ən ʃi hæzən sɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ. ən ɪts ɹænd! aɪ kænt. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt tə du."

Despite herself, Egwene looked around to see if anyone was there to hear. They were alone, with the door closed, but still she spoke just as softly. "I don't know. Maybe." There was no telling what Aes Sedai could do - she had seen enough already to make her believe every story of their powers - and she would not risk eavesdropping. I won't risk Rand. If I did right, I'd tell them, but Moiraine knows, and she hasn't said anything. And it's Rand! I can't. "I don't know what to do."

"hæz æneɪjə sɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ mɔɹ əbaʊt ðiz dʒɹimz?" nɪneɪiv sim tə meɪk ɪɾ ə pɔɪnt nɛvɝ tə æd ði ɑnɝɪfɪk sədaɪ, ivən wən ðə tu ʌv əm wɝ əloʊn. moʊst ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ əpɪɹd nɑt tə kɛɹ, bʌt ðə hæbət hæɾ ɝn ə fju stʃɹeɪnʒ lʊks, ən səm hɑɹd wʌnz; ʃi wɑz gɑnə tʃɹeɪn ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, æftɝ ɔl.

"Has Anaiya said anything more about these dreams?" Nynaeve seemed to make it a point never to add the honorific Sedai, even when the two of them were alone. Most of the Aes Sedai appeared not to care, but the habit had earned a few strange looks, and some hard ones; she was going to train in the White Tower, after all.

" 'ðə wil wivz əz ðə wil wɪlz,' " ɛɡwin kwoʊɾəd æneɪjə. " 'ðə bɔɪ ɪz fɑɹ əweɪ, tʃaɪld, ən ðɛɹz nʌθɪŋ wi kən də əntɪl wi noʊ mɔɹ. əl si tə tɛstɪŋ jə maɪsɛlf wʌns wi ɹitʃ ðə waɪt taʊɝ, tʃaɪld.' ɑɡ! ʃi noʊz ðəɹ ɪz sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ðiz dʒɹimz. aɪ kən tɛl ʃi dʌz. aɪ laɪk ðə wʊmən, nɪneɪiv; aɪ du. bʌt ʃi woʊn tɛl mi wʌɾ aɪ wɑnə noʊ. ən aɪ kæn tɛl əɹ ɛvɹiθɪŋ. meɪbi ɪf aɪ kʊd. . . ."

" 'The Wheel weaves as the Wheel wills,' " Egwene quoted Anaiya. " 'The boy is far away, child, and there's nothing we can do until we know more. I will see to testing you myself once we reach the White Tower, child.' Aaagh! She knows there is something in these dreams. I can tell she does. I like the woman, Nynaeve; I do. But she won't tell me what I want to know. And I can't tell her everything. Maybe if I could. . . ."

"ðə mæn ɪn ðə mæsk əɡɛn?"

"The man in the mask again?"

ɛɡwin nɑɾəd. sʌmhaʊ, ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz bɛɾɝ nɑt tə tɛl æneɪjə əbaʊt hɪm. ʃi kəd nɑɾ ɪmædʒən waɪ, bʌt ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ. θɹi taɪmz ðə mæn huz aɪz wɝ faɪɝ hæd bɪn ɪn əɹ dʒɹimz itʃ taɪm wən ʃi dʒɹimd ə dʒɹim ðət kənvɪnst əɹ ɹænd wɑz ɪn deɪnʒɝ. hi ɔlweɪz wɔɹ ə mæsk əkɹɔs ɪz feɪs; səmtaɪmz ʃi kəd si hɪz aɪz, ən səmtaɪmz ʃi kəɾ oʊnli si faɪɝ wɛɹ ðeɪ ʃəd bi. "hi læft ət mi. ɪt wɑz soʊ . . . kəntɛmptʃuəs. əz ðoʊ aɪ wɝ ə pʌpi hi wɑz gɑnə hæv tə pʊʃ aʊɾ ə hɪz weɪ wɪð ɪz fʊt. ɪt fɹaɪɾənz mi. hi fɹaɪɾənz mi."

Egwene nodded. Somehow, she was sure it was better not to tell Anaiya about him. She could not imagine why, but she was sure. Three times the man whose eyes were fire had been in her dreams each time when she dreamed a dream that convinced her Rand was in danger. He always wore a mask across his face; sometimes she could see his eyes, and sometimes she could only see fire where they should be. "He laughed at me. It was so . . . contemptuous. As though I were a puppy he was going to have to push out of his way with his foot. It frightens me. He frightens me."

"ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ ɪts ɛniθɪŋ tə də wɪð ði ʌðɝ dʒɹimz, wɪð ɹænd? səmtaɪmz ə dʒɹim ɪz dʒʌst ə dʒɹim."

"Are you sure it has anything to do with the other dreams, with Rand? Sometimes a dream is just a dream."

ɛɡwin θɹu ʌp əɹ hænz. "æn səmtaɪmz, nɪneɪiv, jə saʊn dʒʌs laɪk æneɪjə sədaɪ!" ʃi pʊɾ ə spɛʃəl ɛmfəsəs ɑn ðə taɪɾəl, ən wɑz pliz tə si nɪneɪiv ɡɹɪmɑs.

Egwene threw up her hands. "And sometimes, Nynaeve, you sound just like Anaiya Sedai!" She put a special emphasis on the title, and was pleased to see Nynaeve grimace.

"ɪf aɪ ɛvɝ ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə ðɪs bɛd, ɛɡwin - "

"If I ever get out of this bed, Egwene - "

ə nɑk ət ðə dɔɹ kʌɾ ɔf wʌtɛvɝ nɪneɪiv hæd bɪn ɡoʊɪŋ tə seɪ. bɪfɔɹ ɛɡwin kəd spik əɹ muv, ði æmɪɝlɪn hɝsɛlf keɪm ɪn ən ʃʌt ðə dɔɹ bɪhaɪn hɝ. ʃi wɑz əloʊn, fəɹ ə wʌndɝ; ʃi sɛldəm lɛft əɹ kæbən, ən ðən ɔlweɪz wɪð lin əɾ əɹ saɪd, ən meɪbi ənʌðɝ ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ.

A knock at the door cut off whatever Nynaeve had been going to say. Before Egwene could speak or move, the Amyrlin herself came in and shut the door behind her. She was alone, for a wonder; she seldom left her cabin, and then always with Leane at her side, and maybe another of the Aes Sedai.

ɛɡwin spɹæŋ tə hɝ fit. ðə ɹum wɑz ə lɪɾəl kɹaʊɾəd, wɪð θɹi ʌv əm ɪn ɪt.

Egwene sprang to her feet. The room was a little crowded, with three of them in it.

"boʊθ ə jə filɪŋ wɛl?" ði æmɪɝlɪn sɛd tʃiɹəli. ʃi tɪltəɾ əɹ hɛɾ ət nɪneɪiv. "iɾɪŋ wɛl, tu, aɪ tʃɹʌst? ɪn ɡʊd tɛmpɝ?"

"Both of you feeling well?" the Amyrlin said cheerily. She tilted her head at Nynaeve. "Eating well, too, I trust? In good temper?"

nɪneɪiv stʃɹʌɡəl tə ə sɪɾɪŋ pəzɪʃən, wɪð əɹ bæk əɡɛns ðə wɔl. "maɪ tɛmpɝ ɪz dʒʌs faɪn, θæŋk ju."

Nynaeve struggled to a sitting position, with her back against the wall. "My temper is just fine, thank you."

"wi ɑɹ ɑnɝd, mʌðɝ," ɛɡwin bɪɡæn, bʌt ði æmɪɝlɪn weɪvd əɹ tə saɪləns.

"We are honored, Mother," Egwene began, but the Amyrlin waved her to silence.

"ɪts ɡʊd tə bi ɑn ðə wɔɾɝ əɡɛn, bʌɾ ɪt ɡɹoʊz bɔɹɪŋ əz ə mɪl pɑn æftɝ ə waɪl wɪð nʌθɪŋ tə du." ðə ʃɪp hild, ən ʃi ʃɪftəɾ əɹ bæləns wɪθaʊt simɪŋ tə noʊɾəs. "aɪ wɪl ɡɪv jə jəɹ lɛsən tədeɪ." ʃi foʊldəd hɝsɛlf ɑntu ði ɛn ʌv ɛɡwinz bɛd, fit tʌkt ʌndɝ hɝ. "sɪt, tʃaɪld."

"It's good to be on the water again, but it grows boring as a mill pond after a while with nothing to do." The ship heeled, and she shifted her balance without seeming to notice. "I will give you your lesson today." She folded herself onto the end of Egwene's bed, feet tucked under her. "Sit, child."

ɛɡwin sæt, bʌt nɪneɪiv bɪɡæn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʊʃ hɝsɛlf tə hɝ fit. "aɪ θɪŋk əl ɡoʊ ɑn dɛk."

Egwene sat, but Nynaeve began trying to push herself to her feet. "I think I will go on deck."

"aɪ sɛd, sɪt!" ði æmɪɝlɪnz vɔɪs kɹæk laɪk ə wɪp, bʌt nɪneɪiv kɛpt ɹaɪzɪŋ, weɪvɝɪŋ. ʃi stɪl hæd boʊθ hænz ɑn ðə bɛd, bʌt ʃi wɑz ɔlmoʊst əpɹaɪt. ɛɡwin hɛl hɝsɛlf ɹɛɾi tə kætʃ əɹ wən ʃi fɛl.

"I said, sit!" The Amyrlin's voice cracked like a whip, but Nynaeve kept rising, wavering. She still had both hands on the bed, but she was almost upright. Egwene held herself ready to catch her when she fell.

kloʊzɪŋ əɹ aɪz, nɪneɪiv sloʊli loʊɝd hɝsɛlf bæk tə ðə bɛd. "pɝhæps əl steɪ. ɪts noʊ daʊt wɪndi ʌp ðɛɹ."

Closing her eyes, Nynaeve slowly lowered herself back to the bed. "Perhaps I will stay. It is no doubt windy up there."

ði æmɪɝlɪn bɑɹkt ə læf. "ðeɪ toʊl mi jə hæɾ ə tɛmpɝ ɪn jə laɪk ə fɪʃɝ-bɝd wɪð ə boʊn ɪn ɪts θɹoʊt. səm ə ðɛm, tʃaɪld, seɪ jud də wɛl fəɹ səm taɪm əz ə nɑvəs, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ oʊl jə ɑɹ. aɪ seɪ, ɪf juv ði əbɪləɾi aɪ hɪɹ ʌv, jə dɪzɝv tə bi wʌn ə ði æksɛptɪd." ʃi ɡeɪv ənʌðɝ læf. "aɪ ɔlweɪz bɪliv ɪn ɡɪvɪŋ pipəl wʌt ðeɪ dɪzɝv. jɛs. aɪ səspɛk jəl lɝn ə ɡɹeɪt dil wʌns jə ɹitʃ ðə waɪt taʊɝ."

The Amyrlin barked a laugh. "They told me you had a temper in you like a fisher-bird with a bone in its throat. Some of them, child, say you'd do well for some time as a novice, no matter how old you are. I say, if you have the ability I hear of, you deserve to be one of the Accepted." She gave another laugh. "I always believe in giving people what they deserve. Yes. I suspect you will learn a great deal once you reach the White Tower."

"aɪd ɹæðɝ wʌn ə ðə wɔɹɾɝz tɔt mi haʊ tə juz ə sɔɹd," nɪneɪiv ɡɹaʊld. ʃi swɑloʊd kənvʌlsɪvli, ən oʊpən əɹ aɪz. "ðɛɹ ɪz sʌmwʌn aɪd laɪk tə juz ɪɾ ɑn." ɛɡwin lʊkt əɾ əɹ ʃɑɹpli; dɪd nɪneɪiv min ði æmɪɝlɪn - wɪtʃ wɑz stupəd, ən deɪnʒɝəs bɪsaɪdz - əɹ læn? ʃi snæpt əɾ ɛɡwin ɛvɹi taɪm læn wɑz mɛnʃənd.

"I'd rather one of the Warders taught me how to use a sword," Nynaeve growled. She swallowed convulsively, and opened her eyes. "There is someone I'd like to use it on." Egwene looked at her sharply; did Nynaeve mean the Amyrlin - which was stupid, and dangerous besides - or Lan? She snapped at Egwene every time Lan was mentioned.

"ə sɔɹd?" ði æmɪɝlɪn sɛd. "aɪ nɛvɝ θɔt sɔɹdz wɝ mʌtʃ juz - ivən ɪf juv ðə skɪl, tʃaɪld, ðəɹ ɑɹ ɔlweɪz mɛn u hæv əz mʌtʃ, ən ə dil mɔɹ stʃɹɛŋkθ - bʌɾ ɪf jə wɑn ə sɔɹd. . . ." ʃi hɛld ʌp əɹ hænd - ɛɡwin ɡæspt, ən ivən nɪneɪivz aɪz bʌlʒd - ən ðəɹ wɑz ə sɔɹɾ ɪn ɪt. wɪð bleɪɾ ən hɪlt ʌv ən ɑd bluɪʃ waɪt, ɪt lʊk sʌmhaʊ . . . koʊld. "meɪd fɹəm ði ɛɹ, tʃaɪld, wɪð ɛɹ. ɪts əz ɡʊɾ əz moʊst stil bleɪdz, bɛɾɝ ðən moʊst, bʌt stɪl nɑt mʌtʃ juz." ðə sɔɹd bɪkeɪm ə pɛɹɪŋ naɪf. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ʃɹɪŋkɪŋ; ɪt dʒʌst wɑz wʌn θɪŋ, ðən ði ʌðɝ. "ðɪs, naʊ, ɪz jusfəl." ðə pɛɹɪŋ naɪf tɝn tə mɪst, ən ðə mɪs feɪɾəd əweɪ. ði æmɪɝlɪn pʊɾ əɹ ɛmpti hæn bæk ɪn əɹ læp.
