"bʌɾ iðɝ teɪks mɔɹ ɛfɝt ðən ɪts wɝθ. bɛɾɝ, iziɝ, sɪmpli tə kæɹi ə ɡʊd naɪf wɪð ju. juv tə lɝn wən tə juz jəɹ əbɪləɾi, əz wɛl əz haʊ, ən wən ɪts bɛɾɝ tə də θɪŋz ðə weɪ ɛni ʌðɝ wʊmən wʊd. lɛɾ ə blæksmɪθ meɪk naɪvz fəɹ ɡʌɾɪŋ fɪʃ. juz ðə wʌn paʊɝ tu ɔfən ən tu fɹili, ən jə kən kʌm tə laɪk ɪt tu mʌtʃ. ðət weɪ laɪz deɪnʒɝ. jə bɪɡɪn tə wɑn mɔɹ ʌv ɪt, ən sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ jə ɹʌn ðə ɹɪsk ə dʒɹɔɪŋ mɔɹ ðən juv lɝn tə hændəl. ən ðət kən bɝn jə aʊt laɪk ə ɡʌɾɝd kændəl, əɹ - "

"A sword?" the Amyrlin said. "I never thought swords were much use - even if you have the skill, child, there are always men who have as much, and a deal more strength - but if you want a sword. . . ." She held up her hand - Egwene gasped, and even Nynaeve's eyes bulged - and there was a sword in it. With blade and hilt of an odd bluish white, it looked somehow . . . cold. "Made from the air, child, with Air. It's as good as most steel blades, better than most, but still not much use." The sword became a paring knife. There was no shrinking; it just was one thing, then the other. "This, now, is useful." The paring knife turned to mist, and the mist faded away. The Amyrlin put her empty hand back in her lap. "But either takes more effort than it is worth. Better, easier, simply to carry a good knife with you. You have to learn when to use your ability, as well as how, and when it's better to do things the way any other woman would. Let a blacksmith make knives for gutting fish. Use the One Power too often and too freely, and you can come to like it too much. That way lies danger. You begin to want more of it, and sooner or later you run the risk of drawing more than you've learned to handle. And that can burn you out like a guttered candle, or - "

"ɪf aɪ mʌs lɝn ɔl ðɪs," nɪneɪiv bɹoʊk ɪn stɪfli, "aɪ wəɾ əz sun lɝn sʌmθɪŋ jusfəl. ɔl ðɪs - ðɪs . . . 'meɪk ði ɛɹ stɝ, nɪneɪiv. laɪt ðə kændəl, nɪneɪiv. naʊ pʊɾ ɪɾ aʊt. laɪɾ ɪɾ əɡɛn.' pɑ!"

"If I must learn all this," Nynaeve broke in stiffly, "I would as soon learn something useful. All this - this . . . 'Make the air stir, Nynaeve. Light the candle, Nynaeve. Now put it out. Light it again.' Paah!"

ɛɡwin kloʊzd əɹ aɪz fəɹ ə moʊmənt. pliz, nɪneɪiv. pliz kip ə tʃɛk ɑn jəɹ tɛmpɝ. ʃi bɪɾ əɹ lɪp tə kip fɹəm seɪɪŋ ɪɾ aʊt laʊd.

Egwene closed her eyes for a moment. Please, Nynaeve. Please keep a check on your temper. She bit her lip to keep from saying it out loud.

ði æmɪɝlɪn wɑz saɪlən fəɹ ə moʊmənt. "jusfəl," ʃi sɛɾ ət læst. "sʌmθɪŋ jusfəl. jə wɑntəɾ ə sɔɹd. səpoʊz ə mæn keɪm ət mi wɪð ə sɔɹd. wʌt wəɾ aɪ du? sʌmθɪŋ jusfəl, jə kən bi ʃʊɹ. ðɪs, aɪ θɪŋk."

The Amyrlin was silent for a moment. "Useful," she said at last. "Something useful. You wanted a sword. Suppose a man came at me with a sword. What would I do? Something useful, you can be sure. This, I think."

fəɹ ən ɪnstənt, ɛɡwin θɔt ʃi sɔ ə ɡloʊ ɝaʊn ðə wʊmən ət ði ʌðɝ ɛn ə hɝ bɛd. ðən ði ɛɹ sim tə θɪkən; nʌθɪŋ tʃeɪnʒd ðəɾ ɛɡwin kəd si, bʌt ʃi kəd ʃʊɹli fil ɪt. ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə lɪft əɹ ɑɹm; ɪt dɪd nɑt bʌdʒ ɛni mɔɹ ðən ɪf ʃi wɝ bɛɹid tə hɝ nɛk ɪn θɪk dʒɛli. nʌθɪŋ kəd muv ɪksɛpt əɹ hɛd.

For an instant, Egwene thought she saw a glow around the woman at the other end of her bed. Then the air seemed to thicken; nothing changed that Egwene could see, but she could surely feel it. She tried to lift her arm; it did not budge any more than if she were buried to her neck in thick jelly. Nothing could move except her head.

"ɹilis mi!" nɪneɪiv ɡɹeɪɾɪd. hɝ aɪz ɡlɛɹd, ən əɹ hɛd dʒɝk fɹəm saɪd tə saɪd, bʌt ðə ɹɛst ə hɝ sæɾ əz ɹɪdʒɪdli əz ə stætʃu. ɛɡwin ɹilaɪz ðət ʃi wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn hɛld. "lɛt mi ɡoʊ!"

"Release me!" Nynaeve grated. Her eyes glared, and her head jerked from side to side, but the rest of her sat as rigidly as a statue. Egwene realized that she was not the only one held. "Let me go!"

"jusfəl, wʊdn jə seɪ? ən ɪts nʌθɪŋ bʌɾ ɛɹ." ði æmɪɝlɪn spoʊk ɪn ə kɑnvɝseɪʃənəl toʊn, əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ ɔl tʃæɾɪŋ oʊvɝ ti. "bɪɡ mæn, wɪð ɪz mʌsəlz ən ɪz sɔɹd, ən ðə sɔɹd dʌz ɪm əz mʌtʃ ɡʊɾ əz ðə hɛɹ ɑn ɪz tʃɛst."

"Useful, wouldn't you say? And it is nothing but Air." The Amyrlin spoke in a conversational tone, as if they were all chatting over tea. "Big man, with his muscles and his sword, and the sword does him as much good as the hair on his chest."

"lɛt mi ɡoʊ, aɪ seɪ!"

"Let me go, I say!"

"æn ɪf aɪ doʊn laɪk wɛɹ i ɪz, waɪ, aɪ kən pɪk ɪm ʌp." nɪneɪiv skwɔk fjʊɹiəsli əz ʃi sloʊli ɹoʊz, stɪl ɪn ə sɪɾɪŋ pəzɪʃən, əntɪl əɹ hɛɾ ɔlmoʊs tʌtʃt ðə silɪŋ. ði æmɪɝlɪn smaɪld. "aɪv ɔfən wɪʃt aɪ kəd juz ðɪs tə flaɪ. ðə ɹɛkɝdz seɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd flaɪ, ɪn ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz, bʌt ðeɪ ɑɹən klɪɹ ɑn haʊ, ɪɡzækli. nɑt ðɪs weɪ, ðoʊ. ɪt dʌznt wɝk laɪk ðæt. jə maɪt ɹitʃ aʊt wɪð jəɹ hænz ən pɪk ʌp ə tʃɛs ðət weɪz əz mʌtʃ əz jə du; jə lʊk stʃɹɔŋ. bʌt teɪk hoʊld ə jɝsɛlf haʊɛvɝ jə wɪl, jə kænɑt pɪk jɝsɛlf ʌp."

"And if I don't like where he is, why, I can pick him up." Nynaeve squawked furiously as she slowly rose, still in a sitting position, until her head almost touched the ceiling. The Amyrlin smiled. "I've often wished I could use this to fly. The records say Aes Sedai could fly, in the Age of Legends, but they aren't clear on how, exactly. Not this way, though. It doesn't work like that. You might reach out with your hands and pick up a chest that weighs as much as you do; you look strong. But take hold of yourself however you will, you cannot pick yourself up."

nɪneɪivz hɛd dʒɝk fjʊɹiəsli, bʌt nɑɾ ənʌðɝ mʌsəl ə hɝ twɪtʃt. "ðə laɪt bɝn ju, lemi ɡoʊ!"

Nynaeve's head jerked furiously, but not another muscle of her twitched. "The Light burn you, let me go!"

ɛɡwin swɑloʊd hɑɹɾ ən hoʊpt ʃi wɑz nɑɾ ɔlsoʊ tə bi lɪftəd.

Egwene swallowed hard and hoped she was not also to be lifted.

"soʊ," ði æmɪɝlɪn kəntɪnjud, "bɪɡ, hɛɹi mæn, ən soʊ fɔɹθ. hi kən də nʌθɪŋ tə mi, waɪl aɪ kən də ɛniθɪŋ əɾ ɔl tə hɪm. waɪ, ɪf aɪ hæɾ ə maɪn tə" - ʃi lin fɔɹwɝd, hɝ aɪz ɪntɛn ɑn nɪneɪiv; sʌɾənli hɝ smaɪl dɪd nɑt sim vɛɹi fɹɛnli - "aɪ kəd tɝn ɪm ʌpsaɪd daʊn ən pæɾəl ɪz bɑɾəm. dʒʌs laɪk - " sʌɾənli ði æmɪɝlɪn flu bækwɝdz soʊ hɑɹɾ əɹ hɛd ɹɪbaʊndɪd fɹəm ðə wɔl, ən ðəɹ ʃi steɪd, əz ɪf sʌmθɪŋ wɝ pɹɛsɪŋ əɡɛns hɝ.

"So," the Amyrlin continued, "big, hairy man, and so forth. He can do nothing to me, while I can do anything at all to him. Why, if I had a mind to" - she leaned forward, her eyes intent on Nynaeve; suddenly her smile did not seem very friendly - "I could turn him upside down and paddle his bottom. Just like - " Suddenly the Amyrlin flew backwards so hard her head rebounded from the wall, and there she stayed, as if something were pressing against her.

ɛɡwin stɛɹd, hɝ maʊθ dʒɹaɪ. ðɪs ɪzən hæpənɪŋ. ɪɾ ɪzənt.

Egwene stared, her mouth dry. This isn't happening. It isn't.

"ðeɪ wɝ ɹaɪt," ði æmɪɝlɪn sɛd. hɝ vɔɪs saʊndəd stʃɹeɪnd, əz ðoʊ ʃi faʊn ɪt hɑɹd tə bɹið. "ðeɪ sɛd jə lɝn kwɪkli. ən ðeɪ sɛɾ ɪt tʊk jəɹ tɛmpɝ bɝnɪŋ tə ɡɛt tə ðə hɑɹɾ ʌv wʌt jə kən du." ʃi tʊk ə stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ bɹɛθ. "ʃæl wi ɹilis itʃ ʌðɝ təɡɛðɝ, tʃaɪld?"

"They were right," the Amyrlin said. Her voice sounded strained, as though she found it hard to breathe. "They said you learned quickly. And they said it took your temper burning to get to the heart of what you can do." She took a struggling breath. "Shall we release each other together, child?"

nɪneɪiv, floʊɾɪŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ wɪð əɹ aɪz əbleɪz, sɛd, "ju lemi ɡoʊ ɹaɪt naʊ, əɹ əl - " əbɹʌpli ə lʊk ʌv əmeɪzmən keɪm oʊvɝ əɹ feɪs, ə lʊk ə lɔs. hɝ maʊθ wɝk saɪlənli.

Nynaeve, floating in the air with her eyes ablaze, said, "You let me go right now, or I'll - " Abruptly a look of amazement came over her face, a look of loss. Her mouth worked silently.

ði æmɪɝlɪn sæɾ ʌp, wɝkɪŋ əɹ ʃoʊldɝz. "ju doʊnt noʊ ɛvɹiθɪŋ jɛt, də ju, tʃaɪld? nɑt ðə hʌnʒɹədθ pɑɹɾ ʌv ɛvɹiθɪŋ. jə dɪd nɑt səspɛkt aɪ kəd kʌt jə ɔf fɹəm ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs. jə kən stɪl fil ɪt ðɛɹ, bʌt jə kæn tʌtʃ ɪɾ ɛni mɔɹ ðən ə fɪʃ kən tʌtʃ ðə mun. wən jə lɝn ɪnʌf tə bi ɹeɪz tə fʊl sɪstɝhʊd, noʊ wʌn wʊmən wɪl bi eɪbəl tə də ðət tə ju. ðə stʃɹɔŋɝ jə bɪkʌm, ðə mɔɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪɾəl teɪk tə ʃil jə əɡɛns jəɹ wɪl. dʒju θɪŋk, naʊ, jə wɑnə lɝn?" nɪneɪiv pɹɛst əɹ maʊθ ʃʌɾ ɪn ə θɪn laɪn ən stɛɹɾ əɹ ɪn ði aɪ ɡɹɪmli. ði æmɪɝlɪn saɪd. "ɪf jə hæɾ ə hɛɹ lɛs pətɛnʃəl ðən jə du, tʃaɪld, aɪ wəd sɛn jə tə ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz ən tɛl əɹ tə kip jə ðə ɹɛst ə jəɹ laɪf. bʌt jəl ɡɛt wʌt jə dɪzɝv."

The Amyrlin sat up, working her shoulders. "You don't know everything yet, do you, child? Not the hundredth part of everything. You did not suspect I could cut you off from the True Source. You can still feel it there, but you can't touch it any more than a fish can touch the moon. When you learn enough to be raised to full sisterhood, no one woman will be able to do that to you. The stronger you become, the more Aes Sedai it will take to shield you against your will. Do you think, now, you want to learn?" Nynaeve pressed her mouth shut in a thin line and stared her in the eye grimly. The Amyrlin sighed. "If you had a hair less potential than you do, child, I would send you to the Mistress of Novices and tell her to keep you the rest of your life. But you will get what you deserve."

nɪneɪivz aɪz waɪɾənd, ən ʃi hæd dʒʌs taɪm tə stɑɹɾ ə jɛl bɪfɔɹ ʃi dʒɹɑpt, hɪɾɪŋ əɹ bɛd wɪð ə laʊd θʌd. ɛɡwin wɪnst; ðə mætʃɹəsəz wɝ θɪn, ən ðə wʊd bɪniθ hɑɹd. nɪneɪivz feɪs steɪd fɹoʊzən əz ʃi ʃɪftəd ðə weɪ ʃi sæt, dʒʌst ə fɹækʃən.

Nynaeve's eyes widened, and she had just time to start a yell before she dropped, hitting her bed with a loud thud. Egwene winced; the mattresses were thin, and the wood beneath hard. Nynaeve's face stayed frozen as she shifted the way she sat, just a fraction.

"ænd naʊ," ði æmɪɝlɪn sɛd fɝmli, "ənlɛs jə wəd laɪk fɝðɝ dɛmənstʃɹeɪʃən, wɪl ɡɛɾ ɑn wɪð jəɹ lɛsən. kəntɪnju jəɹ lɛsən, wi maɪt seɪ."

"And now," the Amyrlin said firmly, "unless you would like further demonstration, we will get on with your lesson. Continue your lesson, we might say."

"mʌðɝ?" ɛɡwin sɛd feɪnli. ʃi stɪl kəd nɑt twɪtʃ bɪloʊ hɝ tʃɪn.

"Mother?" Egwene said faintly. She still could not twitch below her chin.

ði æmɪɝlɪn lʊkt əɾ əɹ kwɛstʃənɪŋli, ðən smaɪld. "oʊ. aɪm sɑɹi, tʃaɪld. jəɹ fɹɛnd wɑz ɑkjəpaɪɪŋ maɪ ətɛnʃən, aɪm əfɹeɪd." sʌɾənli ɛɡwin kəd muv əɡɛn; ʃi ɹeɪzd əɹ ɑɹmz, dʒʌs tə kənvɪns hɝsɛlf ðət ʃi kʊd. "ɑɹ jə boʊθ ɹɛɾi tə lɝn?"

The Amyrlin looked at her questioningly, then smiled. "Oh. I am sorry, child. Your friend was occupying my attention, I'm afraid." Suddenly Egwene could move again; she raised her arms, just to convince herself that she could. "Are you both ready to learn?"

"jɛs, mʌðɝ," ɛɡwin sɛd kwɪkli.

"Yes, Mother," Egwene said quickly.

ði æmɪɝlɪn ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ ət nɪneɪiv.

The Amyrlin raised an eyebrow at Nynaeve.

æftɝ ə moʊmənt, nɪneɪiv sɛɾ ɪn ə taɪt vɔɪs, "jɛs, mʌðɝ."

After a moment, Nynaeve said in a tight voice, "Yes, Mother."

ɛɡwin hivd ə saɪ ʌv ɹɪlif.

Egwene heaved a sigh of relief.

"ɡʊd. naʊ, ðɛn. ɛmpti jəɹ θɔts ʌv ɛvɹiθɪŋ bʌɾ ə flaʊɝ bʌd."

"Good. Now, then. Empty your thoughts of everything but a flower bud."

ɛɡwin wɑz swɛɾɪŋ baɪ ðə taɪm ði æmɪɝlɪn lɛft. ʃi hæd θɔt səm ə ði ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd bɪn hɑɹd titʃɝz, bʌt ðət smaɪlɪŋ, pleɪn-feɪst wʊmən koʊkst aʊɾ ɛvɹi læs dʒɹɑp ʌv ɛfɝt, dʒɹu ɪɾ aʊt, ən wən ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ lɛft, ʃi sim tə ɹitʃ ɪndə jə ən pʊld ɪɾ aʊt. ɪt hæd ɡɔn wɛl, ðoʊ. əz ðə dɔɹ kloʊz bɪhaɪn ði æmɪɝlɪn, ɛɡwin ɹeɪzd wʌn hænd; ə taɪni fleɪm spɹæŋ tə laɪf, bælənst ə hɛɹbɹidθ əbʌv ðə tɪp ə hɝ fɔɹfɪŋɡɝ, ðən dæns fɹəm fɪŋɡɝɾɪp tə fɪŋɡɝɾɪp. ʃi wɑz nɑt səpoʊz tə də ðɪs wɪθaʊɾ ə titʃɝ - wʌn ə ði æksɛptɪd, ət ðə vɛɹi list - tə wɑtʃ oʊvɝ hɝ, bʌt ʃi wɑz tu ɪksaɪɾəd əɾ əɹ pɹɑɡɹɛs tə peɪ ɛni maɪn tə ðæt.

Egwene was sweating by the time the Amyrlin left. She had thought some of the other Aes Sedai had been hard teachers, but that smiling, plain-faced woman coaxed out every last drop of effort, drew it out, and when there was nothing left, she seemed to reach into you and pulled it out. It had gone well, though. As the door closed behind the Amyrlin, Egwene raised one hand; a tiny flame sprang to life, balanced a hairbreadth above the tip of her forefinger, then danced from fingertip to fingertip. She was not supposed to do this without a teacher - one of the Accepted, at the very least - to watch over her, but she was too excited at her progress to pay any mind to that.

nɪneɪiv baʊndəd tə hɝ fiɾ ən θɹu hɝ pɪloʊ ət ðə kloʊzɪŋ dɔɹ. "ðæt - ðət vaɪl, kəntɛmptəbəl, mɪzɝəbəl - hæɡ! ðə laɪt bɝn hɝ! aɪd laɪk tə fiɾ əɹ tə ðə fɪʃ. aɪd laɪk tə doʊs əɹ wɪð θɪŋz ðət wəd tɝn əɹ ɡɹin fəɹ ðə ɹɛst ə hɝ laɪf! aɪ doʊn kɛɹ ɪf ʃiz oʊld ɪnʌf tə bi maɪ mʌðɝ, ɪf aɪ hæɾ əɹ ɪn ɛmənz fild, ʃi wʊdn sɪt daʊn kʌmfɝɾəbli fɔɹ. . . ." hɝ tiθ ɡɹaʊn soʊ laʊdli ðəɾ ɛɡwin dʒʌmpt.

Nynaeve bounded to her feet and threw her pillow at the closing door. "That - that vile, contemptible, miserable - hag! The Light burn her! I'd like to feed her to the fish. I'd like to dose her with things that would turn her green for the rest of her life! I don't care if she's old enough to be my mother, if I had her in Emond's Field, she wouldn't sit down comfortably for. . . ." Her teeth ground so loudly that Egwene jumped.

lɛɾɪŋ ðə fleɪm daɪ, ɛɡwin pʊɾ əɹ aɪz fɝmli ɑn əɹ læp. ʃi wɪʃt ʃi kəd θɪŋk ʌv ə weɪ tə snik aʊɾ ə ðə ɹum wɪθaʊt kætʃɪŋ nɪneɪivz aɪ.

Letting the flame die, Egwene put her eyes firmly on her lap. She wished she could think of a way to sneak out of the room without catching Nynaeve's eye.

ðə lɛsən hæd nɑt ɡɔn wɛl fəɹ nɪneɪiv, kəz ʃi hæd hɛld əɹ tɛmpɝ ɑn ə taɪt lɛɾ əntɪl ði æmɪɝlɪn wɑz ɡɔn. ʃi nɛvɝ kəd də vɛɹi mʌtʃ ənlɛs ʃi wɑz æŋɡɹi, ən ðən ɪɾ ɔl bɝst aʊɾ ə hɝ. æftɝ feɪljɝ əpɑn feɪljɝ, ði æmɪɝlɪn hæd dʌn ɛvɹiθɪŋ ʃi kəd tə ɹaʊs əɹ əɡɛn. ɛɡwin wɪʃt nɪneɪiv kəd fɝɡɛt ʃi hæd bɪn ðəɹ tə si əɹ hɪɹ ɛni ʌv ɪt.

The lesson had not gone well for Nynaeve, because she had held her temper on a tight lead until the Amyrlin was gone. She never could do very much unless she was angry, and then it all burst out of her. After failure upon failure, the Amyrlin had done everything she could to rouse her again. Egwene wished Nynaeve could forget she had been there to see or hear any of it.

nɪneɪiv stɔk stɪfli tə hɝ bɛɾ ən stʊd stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə wɔl bɪhaɪn ɪt, hɝ fɪs klɛntʃt əɾ əɹ saɪd. ɛɡwin lʊk lɔŋɪŋli ət ðə dɔɹ.

Nynaeve stalked stiffly to her bed and stood staring at the wall behind it, her fist clenched at her side. Egwene looked longingly at the door.

"ɪt wɑz nɑt jəɹ fɔlt," nɪneɪiv sɛd, ən ɛɡwin ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt.

"It was not your fault," Nynaeve said, and Egwene gave a start.

"nɪneɪiv, aɪ - "

"Nynaeve, I - "

nɪneɪiv tɝn tə lʊk daʊn ət hɝ. "ɪt wɑz nɑt jəɹ fɔlt," ʃi ɹɪpiɾɪd, saʊndɪŋ ʌnkənvɪnst. "bʌɾ ɪf jə ɛvɝ bɹið wʌn wɝd, əl - aɪl. . . ."

Nynaeve turned to look down at her. "It was not your fault," she repeated, sounding unconvinced. "But if you ever breathe one word, I'll - I'll. . . ."

"nɑɾ ə wɝd," ɛɡwin sɛd kwɪkli. "aɪ doʊn ivən ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɛniθɪŋ tə bɹið ə wɝɾ əbaʊt."

"Not a word," Egwene said quickly. "I don't even remember anything to breathe a word about."

nɪneɪiv stɛɹɾ əɾ əɹ ə moʊmən lɔŋɡɝ, ðən nɑɾəd. əbɹʌpli ʃi ɡɹɪməst. "laɪt, aɪ dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ɛniθɪŋ teɪstəd wɝs ðən ɹɔ ʃipstɔŋ ɹut. əl ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðæt, ðə nɛks taɪm jə æk ðə ɡus, soʊ wɑtʃ jɝsɛlf."

Nynaeve stared at her a moment longer, then nodded. Abruptly she grimaced. "Light, I did not think anything tasted worse than raw sheepstongue root. I'll remember that, the next time you act the goose, so watch yourself."

ɛɡwin wɪnst. ðət hæd bɪn ðə fɝs θɪŋ ði æmɪɝlɪn hæd dʌn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹaʊs nɪneɪivz æŋɡɝ. ə dɑɹk ɡlɑb ə sʌmθɪŋ ðət ɡlɪsən laɪk ɡɹis ən smɛl vaɪl hæd sʌɾənli əpɪɹɾ ænd, waɪl ði æmɪɝlɪn hɛl nɪneɪiv wɪð ðə paʊɝ, hæd bɪn fɔɹst ɪndə ðə wɪzdəmz maʊð. ði æmɪɝlɪn hæɾ ivən hɛld əɹ noʊz tə meɪk əɹ swɑloʊ. ən nɪneɪiv ɹɪmɛmbɝd θɪŋz, ɪf ʃi hæd sin əm dʌn wʌns. ɛɡwin dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ðəɹ wɑz ɛni weɪ ʌv stɑpɪŋ əɹ ɪf ʃi tʊk ɪɾ ɪndə hɝ maɪn tə də ɪt; fəɹ ɔl əɹ oʊn səksɛs ɪn meɪkɪŋ ə fleɪm dæns, ʃi kəd nɛvɝ əv hɛl ði æmɪɝlɪn əɡɛnst ə wɔl. "æt lis biɪŋ ɑn ðə ʃɪp ɪzən meɪkɪŋ jə sɪk ɛnimɔɹ."

Egwene winced. That had been the first thing the Amyrlin had done trying to rouse Nynaeve's anger. A dark glob of something that glistened like grease and smelled vile had suddenly appeared and, while the Amyrlin held Nynaeve with the Power, had been forced into the Wisdom's mouth. The Amyrlin had even held her nose to make her swallow. And Nynaeve remembered things, if she had seen them done once. Egwene did not think there was any way of stopping her if she took it into her mind to do it; for all her own success in making a flame dance, she could never have held the Amyrlin against a wall. "At least being on the ship isn't making you sick anymore."

nɪneɪiv ɡɹʌntɪd, ðən ɡeɪv ə ʃɔɹt, ʃɑɹp læf. "aɪm tu æŋɡɹi tə bi sɪk." wɪð ənʌðɝ mɝθləs læf, ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "aɪm tu mɪzɝəbəl tə bi sɪk. laɪt, aɪ fil əz ɪf aɪv bɪn dʒɹæɡd θɹu ə nɑthoʊl bækwɝdz. ɪf ðəɾ ɪz wʌt nɑvəs tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ɪz laɪk, jəl əv ɪnsɛntɪv tə lɝn kwɪkli."

Nynaeve grunted, then gave a short, sharp laugh. "I'm too angry to be sick." With another mirthless laugh, she shook her head. "I'm too miserable to be sick. Light, I feel as if I've been dragged through a knothole backwards. If that is what novice training is like, you will have incentive to learn quickly."

ɛɡwin skaʊld əɾ əɹ niz. kəmpɛɹd tə nɪneɪiv, ði æmɪɝlɪn hæɾ oʊnli koʊks hɝ, smaɪld əɾ əɹ səksɛsəz, sɪmpəθaɪzd wɪð əɹ feɪljɝz, ðən koʊkst əɡɛn. bʌɾ ɔl ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd sɛd θɪŋz wəd bi dɪfɹən ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ; hɑɹɾɝ, ðoʊ ðeɪ wəd nɑt seɪ haʊ. ɪf ʃi hæd tə ɡoʊ θɹu wʌt nɪneɪiv hæd, deɪ æftɝ deɪ, ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ʃi kəd stæn ɪt.

Egwene scowled at her knees. Compared to Nynaeve, the Amyrlin had only coaxed her, smiled at her successes, sympathized with her failures, then coaxed again. But all the Aes Sedai had said things would be different in the White Tower; harder, though they would not say how. If she had to go through what Nynaeve had, day after day, she did not think she could stand it.

sʌmθɪŋ tʃeɪnʒd ɪn ðə moʊʃən ə ðə ʃɪp. ðə ɹɑkɪŋ izd, ən fit θʌmpt ɑn ðə dɛk əbʌv ðɛɹ hɛdz. ə mæn ʃaʊɾəd sʌmθɪŋ ɛɡwin kəd nɑt kwaɪt meɪk aʊt.

Something changed in the motion of the ship. The rocking eased, and feet thumped on the deck above their heads. A man shouted something Egwene could not quite make out.

ʃi lʊkt ʌp ət nɪneɪiv. "du jə θɪŋk. . . . tɑɹ vəlɑn?"

She looked up at Nynaeve. "Do you think. . . . Tar Valon?"

"ðɛɹ ɪz oʊnli wʌn weɪ tə faɪn aʊt," nɪneɪiv ɹɪplaɪd, ən dətɝmənədli tʊk əɹ kloʊk fɹəm ɪts pɛɡ.

"There is only one way to find out," Nynaeve replied, and determinedly took her cloak from its peg.

wən ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə dɛk, seɪlɝz wɝ ɹʌnɪŋ ɛvɹiwɛɹ, hivɪŋ ət laɪnz, ʃɔɹɾənɪŋ seɪl, ɹɛɾiɪŋ lɔŋ swips. ðə wɪn hæd daɪd tə ə bɹiz, ən ðə klaʊdz wɝ skæɾɝɪŋ, naʊ.

When they reached the deck, sailors were running everywhere, heaving at lines, shortening sail, readying long sweeps. The wind had died to a breeze, and the clouds were scattering, now.

ɛɡwin ɹʌʃt tə ðə ɹeɪl. "ɪɾ ɪz! ɪts tɑɹ vəlɑn!" nɪneɪiv dʒɔɪn əɹ wɪð ən ɪkspɹɛʃənləs feɪs.

Egwene rushed to the rail. "It is! It is Tar Valon!" Nynaeve joined her with an expressionless face.

ði aɪlənd wɑz soʊ bɪɡ ɪt lʊk mɔɹ əz ɪf ðə ɹɪvɝ splɪɾ ɪn tu ðən kənteɪn ə bɪɾ ə lænd. bɹɪdʒəz ðət sim tə bi meɪɾ ə leɪs ɑɹtʃt fɹəm iðɝ bæŋk tə ði aɪlənd, kɹɔsɪŋ mɑɹʃi ɡɹaʊn əz wɛl əz ðə ɹɪvɝ. ðə wɔlz ə ðə sɪɾi, ðə ʃaɪnɪŋ wɔlz ə tɑɹ vəlɑn, ɡlɪsənd waɪɾ əz ðə sʌn bɹoʊk θɹu ðə klaʊdz. ən ɑn ðə wɛs bæŋk, ɪts bɹoʊkən tɑp likɪŋ ə θɪn wɪsp ə smoʊk, dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊn ɹɪɹd blæk əɡɛns ðə skaɪ, wʌn maʊntən stændɪŋ əmʌŋ flæt lænz ən ɹoʊlɪŋ hɪlz. dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt, wɛɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən hæd daɪd. dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt, meɪd baɪ ðə dʒɹæɡənz daɪɪŋ.

The island was so big it looked more as if the river split in two than contained a bit of land. Bridges that seemed to be made of lace arched from either bank to the island, crossing marshy ground as well as the river. The walls of the city, the Shining Walls of Tar Valon, glistened white as the sun broke through the clouds. And on the west bank, its broken top leaking a thin wisp of smoke, Dragonmount reared black against the sky, one mountain standing among flat lands and rolling hills. Dragonmount, where the Dragon had died. Dragonmount, made by the Dragon's dying.

ɛɡwin wɪʃt ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ə ɹænd wən ʃi lʊkt ət ðə maʊntən. ə mæn tʃænəlɪŋ. laɪt, hɛlp hɪm.

Egwene wished she did not think of Rand when she looked at the mountain. A man channeling. Light, help him.

ðə ɹɪvɝ kwin pæs θɹu ə waɪɾ oʊpənɪŋ ɪn ə tɔl, sɝkjəlɝ wɔl ðət θɹʌst aʊɾ ɪndə ðə ɹɪvɝ. ɪnsaɪd, wʌn lɔŋ wɔɹf sɝaʊndəɾ ə ɹaʊn hɑɹbɝ. seɪlɝz fɝl ðə læst seɪlz ən juz swips əloʊn tə muv ðə ʃɪp stɝn-fɝs tə ɪts dɑkɪŋ. ɝaʊn ðə lɔŋ wɔɹf, ði ʌðɝ ʃɪps ðət hæd kʌm daʊnɹɪvɝ wɝ naʊ biɪŋ snʌɡd ɪndə ðɛɹ bɝθs əmʌŋ ðə ʃɪps ɔlɹɛɾi ðɛɹ. ðə waɪt fleɪm bænɝ sɛt wɝkɝz skɝiɪŋ əlɔŋ ði ɔlɹɛɾi bɪzi wɔɹf.

The River Queen passed through a wide opening in a tall, circular wall that thrust out into the river. Inside, one long wharf surrounded a round harbor. Sailors furled the last sails and used sweeps alone to move the ship stern-first to its docking. Around the long wharf, the other ships that had come downriver were now being snugged into their berths among the ships already there. The White Flame banner set workers scurrying along the already busy wharf.

ði æmɪɝlɪn keɪm ɑn dɛk bɪfɔɹ ðə ʃɔɹ laɪnz wɝ taɪɾ ɔf, bʌt dɑkwɝkɝz ɹæn ə ɡæŋplæŋk əbɔɹɾ əz sun əz ʃi əpɪɹd. lin wɔkt əɾ əɹ saɪd, fleɪm-tɪp stæf ɪn hænd, ən ði ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑn ðə ʃɪp fɑloʊɾ əm əʃɔɹ. nʌn ə ðɛm soʊ mʌtʃ əz ɡlænst əɾ ɛɡwin əɹ nɪneɪiv. ɑn ðə wɔɹf ə dɛləɡeɪʃən ɡɹiɾəd ði æmɪɝlɪn - ʃɔld ɛɛs sədaɪ, boʊɪŋ fɔɹməli, kɪsɪŋ ði æmɪɝlɪnz ɹɪŋ. ðə wɔɹf bʌsəld, bɪtwin ʃɪps ənloʊɾɪŋ ən ði æmɪɝlɪn siɾ ɝaɪvɪŋ; soʊlʒɝz fɔɹmd ʌp ɑn dɪsɛmbɑɹkɪŋ, mɛn sɛt bumz fəɹ kɑɹɡoʊ; tʃɹʌmpət flɝɪʃəz ɹæŋ fɹəm ðə wɔlz, kəmpiɾɪŋ wɪð tʃɪɹz fɹəm ði ɔnlʊkɝz.

The Amyrlin came on deck before the shore lines were tied off, but dockworkers ran a gangplank aboard as soon as she appeared. Leane walked at her side, flame-tipped staff in hand, and the other Aes Sedai on the ship followed them ashore. None of them so much as glanced at Egwene or Nynaeve. On the wharf a delegation greeted the Amyrlin - shawled Aes Sedai, bowing formally, kissing the Amyrlin's ring. The wharf bustled, between ships unloading and the Amyrlin Seat arriving; soldiers formed up on disembarking, men set booms for cargo; trumpet flourishes rang from the walls, competing with cheers from the onlookers.

nɪneɪiv ɡeɪv ə laʊd snɪf. "ɪt simz ðeɪv fɝɡɑɾən ʌs. kʌm əlɔŋ. wɪl si tə aʊɝsɛlvz."

Nynaeve gave a loud sniff. "It seems they've forgotten us. Come along. We'll see to ourselves."

ɛɡwin wɑz ɹɪlʌktən tə liv əɹ fɝst saɪɾ ə tɑɹ vəlɑn, bʌt ʃi fɑloʊd nɪneɪiv bɪloʊ tə ɡæðɝ ðɛɹ θɪŋz. wən ðeɪ keɪm bæk tɑpsaɪd, bʌndəlz ɪn ðɛɹ ɑɹmz, soʊlʒɝz ən tʃɹʌmpəts wɝ ɡɔn - ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, tu. mɛn wɝ swɪŋɪŋ bæk hætʃɪz əlɔŋ ðə dɛk ən loʊɝɪŋ keɪbəlz ɪndə ðə hoʊlz.

Egwene was reluctant to leave her first sight of Tar Valon, but she followed Nynaeve below to gather their things. When they came back topside, bundles in their arms, soldiers and trumpets were gone - and Aes Sedai, too. Men were swinging back hatches along the deck and lowering cables into the holds.

ɑn ðə dɛk, nɪneɪiv kɑɾ ə dɑkmənz ɑɹm, ə bɝli fɛloʊ ɪn ə kɔɹs bɹaʊn ʃɝt wɪð noʊ slivz. "aʊɝ hɔɹsəz," ʃi bɪɡæn.

On the deck, Nynaeve caught a dockman's arm, a burly fellow in a coarse brown shirt with no sleeves. "Our horses," she began.

"aɪm bɪzi," hi ɡɹaʊld, pʊlɪŋ fɹi. "hɔɹsəzəl ɔl bi tʊk tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ." hi lʊkt əm ʌp ən daʊn. "ɪf juv bɪznəs wɪð ðə taʊɝ, bɛs jə teɪk jʊɹsɛlvz ɑn. ɛɛs sədaɪ doʊn hoʊld wɪð nulɪŋz biɪŋ tɑɹɾi." ənʌðɝ mæn, ɹɛslɪŋ wɪð ə beɪl biɪŋ swʌŋ aʊɾ ə ðə hoʊld ɑn ə keɪbəl, ʃaʊɾəd tə hɪm, ən i lɛf ðə wɪmən wɪθaʊɾ ə bækwɝdz ɡlæns.

"I'm busy," he growled, pulling free. "Horses'll all be took to the White Tower." He looked them up and down. "If you've business with the Tower, best you take yourselves on. Aes Sedai don't hold with newlings being tardy." Another man, wrestling with a bale being swung out of the hold on a cable, shouted to him, and he left the women without a backwards glance.

ɛɡwin ɪkstʃeɪnʒd lʊks wɪð nɪneɪiv. ɪt sim ðeɪ ɹɪli wɝ ɑn ðɛɹ oʊn.

Egwene exchanged looks with Nynaeve. It seemed they really were on their own.

nɪneɪiv stɔkt ɔf ðə ʃɪp wɪð ɡɹɪm dɪtɝməneɪʃən ɑn əɹ feɪs, bʌɾ ɛɡwin meɪɾ əɹ weɪ dɪdʒɛktɪdli daʊn ðə ɡæŋplæŋk ən θɹu ðə tɛɹi smɛl ðət hʌŋ oʊvɝ ðə wɔɹf. ɔl ðət tɔk əbaʊt wɑntɪŋ əs hɪɹ, ən naʊ ðeɪ doʊn sim tə kɛɹ.

Nynaeve stalked off the ship with grim determination on her face, but Egwene made her way dejectedly down the gangplank and through the tarry smell that hung over the wharf. All that talk about wanting us here, and now they don't seem to care.

bɹɔd stɛɹz lɛɾ ʌp fɹəm ðə dɑk tə ə waɪɾ ɑɹtʃ ə dɑɹk ɹɛdstoʊn. ɑn ɹitʃɪŋ ɪt, ɛɡwin ən nɪneɪiv stɑp tə stɛɹ.

Broad stairs led up from the dock to a wide arch of dark redstone. On reaching it, Egwene and Nynaeve stopped to stare.

ɛvɹi bɪldɪŋ simd ə pæləs, ðoʊ moʊst ə ðoʊz kloʊs tə ði ɑɹtʃ sim tə kənteɪn ɪnz əɹ ʃɑps, fɹəm ðə saɪnz oʊvɝ ðə dɔɹz. fænsɪfəl stoʊnwɝk wɑz ɛvɹiwɛɹ, ən ðə laɪnz ʌv wʌn stʃɹʌktʃɝ sim dɪzaɪn tə kɑmpləmən ən sɛɾ ɔf ðə nɛkst, liɾɪŋ ði aɪ əlɔŋ əz ɪf ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɝ pɑɹɾ ʌv wʌn væs dɪzaɪn. səm stʃɹʌktʃɝz dɪd nɑt lʊk laɪk bɪldɪŋz əɾ ɔl, bʌt laɪk dʒaɪɡæntɪk weɪvz bɹeɪkɪŋ, əɹ hjudʒ ʃɛlz, əɹ fænsɪfəl, waɪnd-skʌlptɪd klɪfs. ɹaɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ði ɑɹtʃ leɪ ə bɹɔd skwɛɹ, wɪð ə faʊntən ən tʃɹiz, ən ɛɡwin kəd si ənʌðɝ skwɛɹ fɝðɝ ɑn. əbʌv ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɹoʊz ðə taʊɝz, tɔl ən ɡɹeɪsfəl, səm wɪð swipɪŋ bɹɪdʒəz bɪtwin ðɛm, haɪ ɪn ðə skaɪ. ən oʊvɝ ɔl ɹoʊz wʌn taʊɝ, haɪɝ ən waɪɾɝ ðən ɔl ðə ɹɛst, əz waɪɾ əz ðə ʃaɪnɪŋ wɔlz ðɛmsɛlvz.

Every building seemed a palace, though most of those close to the arch seemed to contain inns or shops, from the signs over the doors. Fanciful stonework was everywhere, and the lines of one structure seemed designed to complement and set off the next, leading the eye along as if everything were part of one vast design. Some structures did not look like buildings at all, but like gigantic waves breaking, or huge shells, or fanciful, wind-sculpted cliffs. Right in front of the arch lay a broad square, with a fountain and trees, and Egwene could see another square further on. Above everything rose the towers, tall and graceful, some with sweeping bridges between them, high in the sky. And over all rose one tower, higher and wider than all the rest, as white as the Shining Walls themselves.

"fɛɹ teɪks ðə bɹɛθ ət fɝst saɪt," sɛɾ ə wʊmənz vɔɪs bɪhaɪn ðɛm. "æt tɛnθ saɪt, fəɹ ðæt. ən ət hʌnʒɹədθ."

"Fair takes the breath at first sight," said a woman's voice behind them. "At tenth sight, for that. And at hundredth."

ɛɡwin tɝnd. ðə wʊmən wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ; ɛɡwin wɑz ʃʊɹ ʌv ɪt, ðoʊ ʃi wɔɹ noʊ ʃɔl. noʊ wʌn ɛls hæd ðəɾ eɪdʒləs lʊk; ən ʃi hɛl hɝsɛlf wɪð ən əʃʊɹəns, ə kɑnfəɾəns ðət sim tə kənfɝm ɪt. ə ɡlæns əɾ əɹ hænd ʃoʊd ðə ɡoʊldən ɹɪŋ, ðə sɝpən baɪɾɪŋ ɪts oʊn teɪl. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑz ə lɪɾəl plʌmp, wɪð ə wɔɹm smaɪl, ən wʌn ə ði ɑɾəst-əpɪɹɪŋ wɪmən ɛɡwin hæɾ ɛvɝ sin. hɝ plʌmpnəs kəd nɑt haɪd haɪ tʃikboʊnz, hɝ aɪz hæɾ ə tɪl tə ðɛm ən wɝ ðə klɪɹɪst, peɪləst ɡɹin, ən əɹ hɛɹ wɑz ɔlmoʊs ðə kʌlɝ ə faɪɝ. ɛɡwin bɛɹli stɑp hɝsɛlf fɹəm ɡɑəlɪŋ ət ðət hɛɹ, ðoʊz slaɪtli slæntəɾ aɪz.

Egwene turned. The woman was Aes Sedai; Egwene was sure of it, though she wore no shawl. No one else had that ageless look; and she held herself with an assurance, a confidence that seemed to confirm it. A glance at her hand showed the golden ring, the serpent biting its own tail. The Aes Sedai was a little plump, with a warm smile, and one of the oddest-appearing women Egwene had ever seen. Her plumpness could not hide high cheekbones, her eyes had a tilt to them and were the clearest, palest green, and her hair was almost the color of fire. Egwene barely stopped herself from goggling at that hair, those slightly slanted eyes.

"oʊɡiɝ bɪlt, ʌv kɔɹs," ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɛn ɑn, "æn ðɛɹ bɛst wɝk ɛvɝ, səm seɪ. wʌn ə ðə fɝst sɪɾiz bɪlt æftɝ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ. ðəɹ wɝn hæf ə θaʊzən pipəl hɪɹ ɔltəɡɛðɝ ðən - noʊ mɔɹ ðən twɛnti sɪstɝz - bʌt ðeɪ bɪl fəɹ wʌt wəd bi niɾəd."

"Ogier built, of course," the Aes Sedai went on, "and their best work ever, some say. One of the first cities built after the Breaking. There weren't half a thousand people here altogether then - no more than twenty sisters - but they built for what would be needed."

"ɪɾ ɪz ə lʌvli sɪɾi," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "wi ɑɹ səpoʊz tə ɡoʊ tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ. wi keɪm hɪɹ fəɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ, bʌt noʊ wʌn simz tə kɛɹ ɪf wi ɡoʊ əɹ steɪ."

"It is a lovely city," Nynaeve said. "We are supposed to go to the White Tower. We came here for training, but no one seems to care if we go or stay."

"ðeɪ kɛɹ," ðə wʊmən sɛd, smaɪlɪŋ. "aɪ keɪm hɪɹ tə mit ju, bʌɾ aɪ wɑz dɪleɪd spikɪŋ wɪð ði æmɪɝlɪn. aɪm ʃɛɹiəm, ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz."

"They care," the woman said, smiling. "I came here to meet you, but I was delayed speaking with the Amyrlin. I am Sheriam, the Mistress of Novices."

"aɪ æm nɑt tə bi ə nɑvəs," nɪneɪiv sɛɾ ɪn ə fɝm vɔɪs, bʌɾ ə lɪɾəl tu kwɪkli. "ði æmɪɝlɪn hɝsɛlf sɛɾ aɪ wɑz tə bi wʌn ə ði æksɛptɪd."

"I am not to be a novice," Nynaeve said in a firm voice, but a little too quickly. "The Amyrlin herself said I was to be one of the Accepted."

"soʊ aɪ wɑz toʊld." ʃɛɹiəm saʊndəɾ əmjuzd. "aɪ hæv nɛvɝ hɝɾ ʌv ɪt biɪŋ dʌn soʊ bɪfɔɹ, bʌt ðeɪ seɪ jə ɑɹ . . . ɪksɛpʃənəl. ɹɪmɛmbɝ, ðoʊ, ivən wʌn ə ði æksɛptɪd kən bi kɔl tə maɪ stʌɾi. ɪt ɹikwaɪɝz mɔɹ bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə ɹulz ðən fəɹ ə nɑvəs, bʌɾ ɪts bɪn noʊn tə hæpən." ʃi tɝn tə ɛɡwin əz ɪf ʃi hæd nɑt sin nɪneɪiv fɹaʊn. "æn jə ɑɹ əɹ nu nɑvəs. ɪts ɔlweɪz ɡʊd tə si ə nɑvəs kʌm. wɪv tu fju, ðiz deɪz. jəl meɪk fɔɹɾi. oʊnli fɔɹɾi. ən noʊ mɔɹ ðən eɪɾ əɹ naɪn ə ðoʊz wɪl bi ɹeɪz tə ði æksɛptɪd. ðoʊ aɪ doʊn θɪŋk jəl əv tə wɝi əbaʊt ðət tu mʌtʃ, ɪf jə wɝk hɑɹɾ ən əplaɪ jɝsɛlf. ðə wɝk ɪz hɑɹd, ən ivən fəɹ wʌn wɪð ðə pətɛnʃəl ðeɪ tɛl mi jə hæv, ɪɾəl nɑt bi meɪɾ ɛni iziɝ. ɪf jə kænɑt stɪk tə ɪt, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ hɑɹɾ ɪɾ ɪz, əɹ ɪf jəl bɹeɪk ʌndɝ ðə stʃɹeɪn, bɛɾɝ wi faɪn ɪɾ aʊt naʊ, ən lɛt jə ɡoʊ ɑn jəɹ weɪ, ðən weɪɾ əntɪl jə ɑɹ ə fʊl sɪstɝ ən ʌðɝz ɑɹ dɪpɛndɪŋ ɑn ju. ən ɛɛs sədaɪz laɪf ɪz nɑɾ izi. hɪɹ, wɪl pɹipɛɹ jə fəɹ ɪt, ɪf juv ɪn jə wʌɾ ɪz ɹikwaɪɝd."

"So I was told." Sheriam sounded amused. "I have never heard of it being done so before, but they say you are . . . exceptional. Remember, though, even one of the Accepted can be called to my study. It requires more breaking of the rules than for a novice, but it has been known to happen." She turned to Egwene as if she had not seen Nynaeve frown. "And you are our new novice. It is always good to see a novice come. We have too few, these days. You will make forty. Only forty. And no more than eight or nine of those will be raised to the Accepted. Though I don't think you will have to worry about that too much, if you work hard and apply yourself. The work is hard, and even for one with the potential they tell me you have, it will not be made any easier. If you cannot stick to it, no matter how hard it is, or if you will break under the strain, better we find it out now, and let you go on your way, than wait until you are a full sister and others are depending on you. An Aes Sedai's life is not easy. Here, we will prepare you for it, if you have in you what is required."

ɛɡwin swɑloʊd. bɹeɪk ʌndɝ ðə stʃɹeɪn? "aɪ wɪl tʃɹaɪ, ʃɛɹiəm sədaɪ," ʃi sɛd feɪnli. ən əl nɑt bɹeɪk.

Egwene swallowed. Break under the strain? "I will try, Sheriam Sedai," she said faintly. And I will not break.

nɪneɪiv lʊkt əɾ əɹ wɝidli. "ʃɛɹiəm. . . ." ʃi stɑpt ən tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. "ʃɛɹiəm sədaɪ" - ʃi sim tə fɔɹs ði ɑnɝɪfɪk aʊt - "dʌz ɪɾ əv tə bi soʊ hɑɹɾ ɑn hɝ? flɛʃ ən blʌd kən oʊnli teɪk soʊ mʌtʃ. aɪ noʊ . . . sʌmθɪŋ . . . ʌv wʌt nɑvəsɪz mʌst ɡoʊ θɹu. ʃʊɹli ðɛɹz noʊ nid tə tʃɹaɪ tə bɹeɪk əɹ dʒʌs tə faɪn aʊt haʊ stʃɹɔŋ ʃi ɪz."

Nynaeve looked at her worriedly. "Sheriam. . . ." She stopped and took a deep breath. "Sheriam Sedai" - she seemed to force the honorific out - "does it have to be so hard on her? Flesh and blood can only take so much. I know . . . something . . . of what novices must go through. Surely there's no need to try to break her just to find out how strong she is."

"ju min wʌt ði æmɪɝlɪn dɪd tə jə tədeɪ?" nɪneɪivz bæk stɪfənd; ʃɛɹiəm lʊkt əz ðoʊ ʃi wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kip əmjuzmən fɹəm əɹ feɪs. "aɪ toʊl jə aɪ spoʊk wɪð ði æmɪɝlɪn. ɹɛs jəɹ wɝiz fəɹ jəɹ fɹɛnd. nɑvəs tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ɪz hɑɹd, bʌt nɑt ðət hɑɹd. ðəɾ ɪz fəɹ ðə fɝs fju wiks ə biɪŋ wʌn ə ði æksɛptɪd." nɪneɪivz maʊθ fɛl oʊpən; ɛɡwin θɔt ðə wɪzdəmz aɪz wɝ gɑnə kʌm ɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ hɛd. "tə kætʃ ðə fju hu maɪɾ əv slɪp θɹu nɑvəs tʃɹeɪnɪŋ wən ðeɪ ʃəd nɑt hæv. wi kænɑt ɹɪsk hævɪŋ wʌn ʌv əɹ nʌmbɝ - ə fʊl ɛɛs sədaɪ - hu wɪl bɹeɪk ʌndɝ ðə stʃɹɛs ə ðə wɝld aʊtsaɪd." ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɡæðɝɾ əm boʊθ ʌp, ən ɑɹm ɝaʊn ðə ʃoʊldɝz ʌv itʃ. nɪneɪiv hɑɹdli sim tə ɹilaɪz wɛɹ ʃi wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ. "kʌm," ʃɛɹiəm sɛd, "aɪ wɪl si jə sɛɾəld ɪn jəɹ ɹumz. ðə waɪt taʊɝ əweɪts."

"You mean what the Amyrlin did to you today?" Nynaeve's back stiffened; Sheriam looked as though she were trying to keep amusement from her face. "I told you I spoke with the Amyrlin. Rest your worries for your friend. Novice training is hard, but not that hard. That is for the first few weeks of being one of the Accepted." Nynaeve's mouth fell open; Egwene thought the Wisdom's eyes were going to come right out of her head. "To catch the few who might have slipped through novice training when they should not have. We cannot risk having one of our number - a full Aes Sedai - who will break under the stress of the world outside." The Aes Sedai gathered them both up, an arm around the shoulders of each. Nynaeve hardly seemed to realize where she was going. "Come," Sheriam said, "I will see you settled in your rooms. The White Tower awaits."


tʃæptɝ naɪntin


CHAPTER 19

bɪniθ ðə dæɡɝ


Beneath the Dagger

naɪɾ ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə kɪnsleɪɝz dæɡɝ wɑz koʊld, əz naɪts ɪn ðə maʊntənz ɑɹ ɔlweɪz koʊld. ðə wɪnd wɪp daʊn fɹəm ðə haɪ piks kæɹiɪŋ ði aɪsaɪnəs ə ðə snoʊkæps. ɹænd ʃɪftəɾ ɑn ðə hɑɹd ɡɹaʊnd, tʌɡɪŋ əɾ ɪz kloʊk ən blæŋkət, ən oʊnli hæf əslip. hɪz hænd wɛn tə hɪz sɔɹd, laɪɪŋ bɪsaɪd hɪm. wʌn mɔɹ deɪ, hi θɔt dʒɹaʊsəli. dʒʌst wʌn mɔɹ, ən ðən wi ɡoʊ. ɪf noʊ wʌn kʌmz təmɑɹoʊ, ɪŋtʃɹ əɹ dɑɹkfɹɛnz wʌn, əl teɪk səlin tə kɛɹhin.

Night on the edge of Kinslayer's Dagger was cold, as nights in the mountains are always cold. The wind whipped down from the high peaks carrying the iciness of the snowcaps. Rand shifted on the hard ground, tugging at his cloak and blanket, and only half asleep. His hand went to his sword, lying beside him. One more day, he thought drowsily. Just one more, and then we go. If no one comes tomorrow, Ingtar or Darkfriends one, I'll take Selene to Cairhien.

hi hæd toʊl hɪmsɛlf ðət bɪfɔɹ. ɛvɹi deɪ ðeɪ hæd bɪn ðəɹ ɑn ðə maʊntənsaɪd, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə pleɪs wɛɹ hʊɹɪn sɛd ðə tʃɹeɪl hæd bɪn, ɪn ðəɾ ʌðɝ wɝld - wɛɹ səlin sɛd ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz wəd ʃʊɹli əpɪɹ ɪn ðɪs wɝld - hi toʊl hɪmsɛlf ɪt wɑz taɪm tə liv. ən səlin tɔkt ə ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ, ən tʌtʃt ɪz ɑɹm, ən lʊkt ɪndə hɪz aɪz, ən bɪfɔɹ i nu ɪɾ i hæɾ əɡɹid tə jɛɾ ənʌðɝ deɪ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ wɛn ɑn.

He had told himself that before. Every day they had been there on the mountainside, watching the place where Hurin said the trail had been, in that other world - where Selene said the Darkfriends would surely appear in this world - he told himself it was time to leave. And Selene talked of the Horn of Valere, and touched his arm, and looked into his eyes, and before he knew it he had agreed to yet another day before they went on.

hi ʃɹʌɡd əɡɛns ðə tʃɪl ə ðə wɪnd, θɪŋkɪŋ ə səlin tʌtʃɪŋ ɪz ɑɹm ən lʊkɪŋ ɪndə hɪz aɪz. ɪf ɛɡwin sɔ ðæt, ʃid ʃɪɹ mi fəɹ ə ʃip, ən səlin, tu. ɛɡwin kəɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bi ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn baɪ naʊ, lɝnɪŋ tə bi ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðə nɛks taɪm ʃi siz mi, ʃɪl pɹɑbli tʃɹaɪ tə dʒɛntəl mi.

He shrugged against the chill of the wind, thinking of Selene touching his arm and looking into his eyes. If Egwene saw that, she'd shear me for a sheep, and Selene, too. Egwene could already be in Tar Valon by now, learning to be an Aes Sedai. The next time she sees me, she'll probably try to gentle me.

əz i ʃɪftəɾ oʊvɝ, hɪz hæn slɪd pæs ðə sɔɹɾ ən tʌtʃt ðə bʌndəl hoʊldɪŋ tɑm mɛɹɪlɪnz hɑɹp ən flut. ʌnkɑnʃəsli, hɪz fɪŋɡɝz taɪɾənd ɑn ðə ɡlimənz kloʊk. aɪ wɑz hæpi ðɛn, aɪ θɪŋk, ivən ɹʌnɪŋ fəɹ maɪ laɪf. pleɪɪŋ ðə flut fəɹ maɪ sʌpɝ. aɪ wɑz tu ɪɡnɝən tə noʊ wʌt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn. ðɛɹz noʊ tɝnɪŋ bæk.

As he shifted over, his hand slid past the sword and touched the bundle holding Thom Merrilin's harp and flute. Unconsciously, his fingers tightened on the gleeman's cloak. I was happy then, I think, even running for my life. Playing the flute for my supper. I was too ignorant to know what was going on. There's no turning back.

ʃɪvɝɪŋ, hi oʊpən ɪz aɪz. ði oʊnli laɪt keɪm fɹəm ðə weɪnɪŋ mun, nɑt fɑɹ pæs fʊl ən loʊ ɪn ðə skaɪ. ə faɪɝ wəd ɡɪv əm əweɪ tə ðoʊz fəɹ hum ðeɪ wɑtʃt. lɔɪəl mʌɾɝd ɪn ɪz slip, ə loʊ ɹʌmbəl. wʌn ə ðə hɔɹsəz stæmpt ə huf. hʊɹɪn hæd ðə fɝst wɑtʃ, fɹəm ə stoʊn aʊtkɹɑp ə lɪɾəl weɪ ʌp ðə maʊntən; hi wəd bi kʌmɪŋ tə weɪk ɹænd fəɹ ɪz tɝn, sun.

Shivering, he opened his eyes. The only light came from the waning moon, not far past full and low in the sky. A fire would give them away to those for whom they watched. Loial muttered in his sleep, a low rumble. One of the horses stamped a hoof. Hurin had the first watch, from a stone outcrop a little way up the mountain; he would be coming to wake Rand for his turn, soon.

ɹænd ɹoʊld oʊvɝ . . . ən stɑpt. ɪn ðə munlaɪɾ i kəd si ðə ʃeɪp ə səlin, bɛndɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz sæɾəlbæɡz, hɝ hænz ɑn ðə bʌkəlz. hɝ waɪt dʒɹɛs ɡæðɝd ðə feɪn laɪt. "du jə nid sʌmθɪŋ?"

Rand rolled over . . . and stopped. In the moonlight he could see the shape of Selene, bending over his saddlebags, her hands on the buckles. Her white dress gathered the faint light. "Do you need something?"

ʃi ɡeɪv ə dʒʌmp, ən stɛɹd təwɔɹd hɪm. "ju - jə stɑɹɾəld mi."

She gave a jump, and stared toward him. "You - you startled me."

hi ɹoʊl tə hɪz fit, ʃɛɾɪŋ ðə blæŋkəɾ ən ɹæpɪŋ ðə kloʊk ɝaʊn hɪmsɛlf, ən wɛn tə hɝ. hi wɑz ʃʊɹ i hæd lɛf ðə sæɾəlbæɡz ɹaɪt baɪ hɪz saɪd wən i leɪ daʊn; hi ɔlweɪz kɛpt əm kloʊs. hi tʊk əm fɹəm hɝ. ɔl ðə bʌkəlz wɝ fæsənd, ivən ðoʊz ɑn ðə saɪd ðət hɛl ðə dæmɪŋ bænɝ. haʊ kən maɪ laɪf dɪpɛn ɑn kipɪŋ ɪt? ɪf ɛnibəɾi siz ɪɾ ən noʊz wʌɾ ɪɾ ɪz, əl daɪ fəɹ hævɪŋ ɪt. hi pɪɹɾ əɾ əɹ səspɪʃəsli.

He rolled to his feet, shedding the blanket and wrapping the cloak around himself, and went to her. He was sure he had left the saddlebags right by his side when he lay down; he always kept them close. He took them from her. All the buckles were fastened, even those on the side that held the damning banner. How can my life depend on keeping it? If anybody sees it and knows what it is, I'll die for having it. He peered at her suspiciously.

səlin steɪd wɛɹ ʃi wɑz, lʊkɪŋ ʌp ət hɪm. ðə mun ɡlɪsən ɪn əɹ dɑɹk aɪz. "ɪt keɪm tə mi," ʃi sɛd, "ðæɾ aɪv bɪn wɛɹɪŋ ðɪs dʒɹɛs tu lɔŋ. aɪ kəd bɹʌʃ ɪt, ət list, ɪf aɪ hæd sʌmθɪŋ ɛls tə wɛɹ waɪl aɪ dɪd. wʌn ə jəɹ ʃɝts, pɝhæps."

Selene stayed where she was, looking up at him. The moon glistened in her dark eyes. "It came to me," she said, "that I've been wearing this dress too long. I could brush it, at least, if I had something else to wear while I did. One of your shirts, perhaps."

ɹænd nɑɾəd, filɪŋ ə sʌɾən ɹɪlif. hɝ dʒɹɛs lʊkt əz klin tə hɪm əz wən i fɝst sɔ hɝ, bʌɾ i nu ðəɾ ɪf ə spɑɾ əpɪɹɾ ɑn ɛɡwinz dʒɹɛs, nʌθɪŋ wəd də bʌt ðət ʃi klin ɪɾ ɪmiɾiətli. "ʌv kɔɹs." hi oʊpən ðə kəpeɪʃəs pɑkəɾ ɪndə wɪtʃ i hæd stʌft ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪksɛp ðə bænɝ ən pʊld aʊt wʌn ə ðə waɪt sɪlk ʃɝts.

Rand nodded, feeling a sudden relief. Her dress looked as clean to him as when he first saw her, but he knew that if a spot appeared on Egwene's dress, nothing would do but that she cleaned it immediately. "Of course." He opened the capacious pocket into which he had stuffed everything except the banner and pulled out one of the white silk shirts.

"θæŋk ju." hɝ hænz wɛn bɪhaɪn əɹ bæk. tə ðə bʌɾənz, hi ɹilaɪzd.

"Thank you." Her hands went behind her back. To the buttons, he realized.

aɪz waɪd, hi spʌn əweɪ fɹəm hɝ.

Eyes wide, he spun away from her.

"ɪf jə kəd hɛlp mi wɪð ðiz, ɪt wəd bi mʌtʃ iziɝ."

"If you could help me with these, it would be much easier."

ɹænd klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊt. "ɪt wəd nɑt bi pɹɑpɝ. ɪɾ ɪzən əz ɪf wi wɝ pɹɑməst, ɔɹ. . . ." stɑp θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt ðæt! jə kən nɛvɝ mɛɹi ɛniwʌn. "ɪt dʒʌst wʊdn bi pɹɑpɝ."

Rand cleared his throat. "It would not be proper. It isn't as if we were promised, or. . . ." Stop thinking about that! You can never marry anyone. "It just wouldn't be proper."

hɝ sɑf læf sɛn ə ʃɪvɝ daʊn ɪz bæk, əz ɪf ʃi hæd ɹʌn ə fɪŋɡɝ əlɔŋ ɪz spaɪn. hi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə lɪsən tə ðə ɹʌsəlɪŋz bɪhaɪn hɪm. hi sɛd, "ɑ . . . təmɑɹoʊ . . . təmɑɹoʊ, wɪl liv fəɹ kɛɹhin."

Her soft laugh sent a shiver down his back, as if she had run a finger along his spine. He tried not to listen to the rustlings behind him. He said, "Ah . . . tomorrow . . . tomorrow, we'll leave for Cairhien."

"ænd wʌɾ ə ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ?"

"And what of the Horn of Valere?"

"meɪbi wi wɝ ɹɔŋ. meɪbi ðeɪ ɑɹ nɑt kʌmɪŋ hɪɹ əɾ ɔl. hʊɹɪn sɛz ðəɹ ɑɹ ə nʌmbɝ ə pæsəz θɹu kɪnsleɪɝz dæɡɝ. ɪf ðeɪ wɛn oʊnli ə lɪɾəl fɝðɝ wɛst, ðeɪ də nɑɾ əv tə kʌm ɪndə ðə maʊntənz əɾ ɔl."

"Maybe we were wrong. Maybe they are not coming here at all. Hurin says there are a number of passes through Kinslayer's Dagger. If they went only a little further west, they do not have to come into the mountains at all."

"bʌt ðə tʃɹeɪl wi fɑloʊd keɪm hɪɹ. ðəl kʌm hɪɹ. ðə hɔɹn wɪl kʌm hɪɹ. jə meɪ tɝn ɝaʊnd, naʊ."

"But the trail we followed came here. They will come here. The Horn will come here. You may turn around, now."

"ju seɪ ðæt, bʌt wi doʊnt noʊ. . . ." hi tɝnd, ən ðə wɝdz daɪɾ ɪn ɪz maʊð. hɝ dʒɹɛs leɪ əkɹɔs əɹ ɑɹm, ən ʃi wɔɹ ɪz ʃɝt, hæŋɪŋ ɪn bæɡi foʊlz ɑn hɝ. ɪt wɑz ə lɔŋ-teɪld ʃɝt, meɪd fəɹ ɪz haɪt, bʌt ʃi wɑz tɔl fəɹ ə wʊmən. ðə bɑɾəm ʌv ɪt keɪm lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən hæfweɪ daʊn əɹ θaɪz. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ əz ɪf i hæd nɛvɝ sin ə ɡɝlz lɛɡz bɪfɔɹ; ɡɝlz ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz ɔlweɪz taɪɾ ʌp ðɛɹ skɝts tə ɡoʊ weɪɾɪŋ ɪn wɔɾɝwʊd pɑnz. bʌt ðeɪ stɑp duɪŋ ɪt wɛl bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ wɝ oʊld ɪnʌf tə bɹeɪd ðɛɹ hɛɹ, ən ðɪs wɑz ɪn ðə dɑɹk, bɪsaɪdz. ðə munlaɪt sim tə meɪk əɹ skɪn ɡloʊ.

"You say that, but we don't know. . . ." He turned, and the words died in his mouth. Her dress lay across her arm, and she wore his shirt, hanging in baggy folds on her. It was a long-tailed shirt, made for his height, but she was tall for a woman. The bottom of it came little more than halfway down her thighs. It was not as if he had never seen a girl's legs before; girls in the Two Rivers always tied up their skirts to go wading in Waterwood ponds. But they stopped doing it well before they were old enough to braid their hair, and this was in the dark, besides. The moonlight seemed to make her skin glow.

"wʌɾ ɪz ɪt jə doʊnt noʊ, ɹænd?"

"What is it you don't know, Rand?"

ðə saʊn ə hɝ vɔɪs ənfɹoʊz ɪz dʒɔɪns. wɪð ə laʊd kɑf, hi wɝl tə feɪs ði ʌðɝ weɪ. "ɑ . . . aɪ θɪŋk . . . ɑ . . . aɪ . . . ɑ. . . ."

The sound of her voice unfroze his joints. With a loud cough, he whirled to face the other way. "Ah . . . I think . . . ah . . . I . . . ah. . . ."

"θɪŋk ə ðə ɡlɔɹi, ɹænd." hɝ hæn tʌtʃt ɪz bæk, ən i ɔlmoʊst ʃeɪm hɪmsɛlf wɪð ə skwik. "θɪŋk ə ðə ɡlɔɹi ðət wɪl kʌm tə ðə wʌn u faɪnz ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ. haʊ pɹaʊɾ əl bi tə stæn bɪsaɪɾ ɪm u hoʊlz ðə hɔɹn. juv noʊ aɪdiə ðə haɪts wɪl skeɪl təɡɛðɝ, jə ən aɪ. wɪð ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ ɪn jəɹ hænd, jə kən bi ə kɪŋ. jə kən bi ənʌðɝ ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ. ju. . . ."

"Think of the glory, Rand." Her hand touched his back, and he almost shamed himself with a squeak. "Think of the glory that will come to the one who finds the Horn of Valere. How proud I'll be to stand beside him who holds the Horn. You have no idea the heights we will scale together, you and I. With the Horn of Valere in your hand, you can be a king. You can be another Artur Hawkwing. You. . . ."

"lɔɹd ɹænd!" hʊɹɪn pæntɪɾ ɪndə ðə kæmpsaɪt. "maɪ lɔɹd, ðeɪ. . . ." hi skɪɾəd tə ə hɔlt, sʌɾənli meɪkɪŋ ə ɡɝɡəlɪŋ saʊnd. hɪz aɪz dʒɹɑp tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ən i stʊd ɹɪŋɪŋ ɪz hænz. "fɝɡɪv mi, maɪ leɪɾi. aɪ dɪdn min tə. . . . aɪ. . . . fɝɡɪv mi."

"Lord Rand!" Hurin panted into the campsite. "My Lord, they. . . ." He skidded to a halt, suddenly making a gurgling sound. His eyes dropped to the ground, and he stood wringing his hands. "Forgive me, my Lady. I didn't mean to. . . . I. . . . Forgive me."

lɔɪəl sæɾ ʌp, hɪz blæŋkəɾ ən kloʊk fɔlɪŋ əweɪ. "wʌts hæpənɪŋ? ɪz ɪt maɪ tɝn tə wɑtʃ ɔlɹɛɾi?" hi lʊk təwɔɹd ɹænd ən səlin, ən ivən ɪn ðə munlaɪt ðə waɪɾənɪŋ ə hɪz aɪz wɑz pleɪn.

Loial sat up, his blanket and cloak falling away. "What's happening? Is it my turn to watch already?" He looked toward Rand and Selene, and even in the moonlight the widening of his eyes was plain.

ɹænd hɝd səlin saɪ bɪhaɪn hɪm. hi stɛpt əweɪ fɹəm hɝ, stɪl nɑt lʊkɪŋ ət hɝ. hɝ lɛɡz ɑɹ soʊ waɪt, soʊ smuð. "wʌɾ ɪz ɪt, hʊɹɪn?" hi meɪɾ ɪz vɔɪs mɔɹ mɑɾɝət; wɑz i æŋɡɹi wɪð hʊɹɪn, hɪmsɛlf, əɹ səlin? noʊ ɹizən tə bi æŋɡɹi wɪð hɝ. "dɪd jə si sʌmθɪŋ, hʊɹɪn?"

Rand heard Selene sigh behind him. He stepped away from her, still not looking at her. Her legs are so white, so smooth. "What is it, Hurin?" He made his voice more moderate; was he angry with Hurin, himself, or Selene? No reason to be angry with her. "Did you see something, Hurin?"

ðə snɪfɝ spoʊk wɪθaʊt ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz aɪz. "ə faɪɝ, maɪ lɔɹd, daʊn ɪn ðə hɪlz. aɪ dɪdn si ɪɾ ət fɝst. ðeɪ meɪɾ ɪt smɔl, ən hɪɾ ɪt, bʌt ðeɪ hɪɾ ɪt fɹəm sʌmbɑɾi fɑloʊɪŋ ðɛm, nɑt sʌmbɑɾi əhɛd, ən ʌp əbʌv. tu maɪlz, lɔɹd ɹænd. lɛs ðən θɹi, fəɹ ʃʊɹ."

The sniffer spoke without raising his eyes. "A fire, my Lord, down in the hills. I didn't see it at first. They made it small, and hid it, but they hid it from somebody following them, not somebody ahead, and up above. Two miles, Lord Rand. Less than three, for sure."

"feɪn," ɹænd sɛd. "ɪŋtʃɹ wəd nɑt bi əfɹeɪɾ ʌv ɛniwʌn fɑloʊɪŋ hɪm. ɪt mʌs bi feɪn." sʌɾənli hi dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt tə du, naʊ. ðeɪ hæd bɪn weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ feɪn, bʌt naʊ ðət ðə mæn wɑz oʊnli ə maɪl əɹ soʊ əweɪ, hi wɑz ənsɝɾən. "ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ. . . . ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ, wɪl fɑloʊ. wən ɪŋtʃɹ ən ði ʌðɝz kætʃ ʌp, wɪl bi eɪbəl tə pɔɪn ɹaɪt tə ðɛm."

"Fain," Rand said. "Ingtar would not be afraid of anyone following him. It must be Fain." Suddenly he did not know what to do, now. They had been waiting for Fain, but now that the man was only a mile or so away, he was uncertain. "In the morning. . . . In the morning, we will follow. When Ingtar and the others catch up, we'll be able to point right to them."

"soʊ," səlin sɛd. "ju wɪl lɛt ðɪs ɪŋtʃɹ teɪk ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ. ən ðə ɡlɔɹi."

"So," Selene said. "You will let this Ingtar take the Horn of Valere. And the glory."

"aɪ doʊnt wɑnt. . . ." wɪθaʊt θɪŋkɪŋ, hi tɝnd, ən ðəɹ ʃi wɑz, lɛɡz peɪl ɪn ðə munlaɪt, ən əz ʌnkənsɝn ðət ðeɪ wɝ bɛɹ əz ɪf ʃi wɝ əloʊn. əz ɪf wi wɝ əloʊn, ðə θɔt keɪm. ʃi wɑns ðə mæn u faɪnz ðə hɔɹn. "θɹi ʌv əs kænɑt teɪk ɪɾ əweɪ fɹəm ðɛm. ɪŋtʃɹ əz twɛnti lænsɪz wɪð hɪm."

"I don't want. . . ." Without thinking, he turned, and there she was, legs pale in the moonlight, and as unconcerned that they were bare as if she were alone. As if we were alone, the thought came. She wants the man who finds the Horn. "Three of us cannot take it away from them. Ingtar has twenty lances with him."

"ju doʊnt noʊ jə kænɑt teɪk ɪt. haʊ mɛni fɑloʊɝz dʌz ðɪs mæn hæv? jə doʊnt noʊ ðæt, iðɝ." hɝ vɔɪs wɑz kɑm, bʌɾ ɪntɛnt. "ju doʊn ivən noʊ ɪf ðiz mɛn kæmp daʊn ðəɹ də hæv ðə hɔɹn. ði oʊnli weɪ ɪz tə ɡoʊ daʊn jɝsɛlf ən si. teɪk ði ælɑntɪn; hɪz kaɪn əv ʃɑɹp aɪz, ivən baɪ munlaɪt. ən hiz ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ tə kæɹi ðə hɔɹn ɪn ɪts tʃɛst, ɪf jə meɪk ðə ɹaɪt dɪsɪʒən."

"You don't know you cannot take it. How many followers does this man have? You don't know that, either." Her voice was calm, but intent. "You don't even know if these men camped down there do have the Horn. The only way is to go down yourself and see. Take the alantin; his kind have sharp eyes, even by moonlight. And he has the strength to carry the Horn in its chest, if you make the right decision."

ʃiz ɹaɪt. jə də nɑt noʊ fəɹ ʃʊɹ ɪf ɪts feɪn. ə faɪn θɪŋ ɪt wəd bi tə hæv hʊɹɪn kæstɪŋ əbaʊt fəɹ ə tʃɹeɪl ðət wɑz nɑt ðɛɹ, ɔl ə ðɛm aʊɾ ɪn ði oʊpən ɪf ðə ɹil dɑɹkfɹɛnz dɪd faɪnəli kʌm. "aɪ wɪl ɡoʊ əloʊn," hi sɛd. "hʊɹɪn ən lɔɪəl wɪl stænd ɡɑɹd fəɹ ju."

She's right. You do not know for sure if it's Fain. A fine thing it would be to have Hurin casting about for a trail that was not there, all of them out in the open if the real Darkfriends did finally come. "I will go alone," he said. "Hurin and Loial will stand guard for you."

læfɪŋ, səlin keɪm tə hɪm soʊ ɡɹeɪsfəli ɪɾ ɔlmoʊst simd ʃi dænst. munʃæɾoʊz veɪld əɹ feɪs ɪn mɪstɝi əz ʃi lʊkt ʌp ət hɪm, ən mɪstɝi meɪɾ əɹ ivən mɔɹ bjuɾəfəl. "aɪ æm keɪpəbəl ʌv ɡɑɹɾɪŋ maɪsɛlf, əntɪl jə ɹɪtɝn tə pɹətɛk mi. teɪk ði ælɑntɪn."

Laughing, Selene came to him so gracefully it almost seemed she danced. Moonshadows veiled her face in mystery as she looked up at him, and mystery made her even more beautiful. "I am capable of guarding myself, until you return to protect me. Take the alantin."

"ʃi ɪz ɹaɪt, ɹænd," lɔɪəl sɛd, ɹaɪzɪŋ. "aɪ kən si bɛɾɝ baɪ munlaɪt ðən ju. wɪð maɪ aɪz, wi meɪ nɑt nid tə ɡoʊ əz kloʊs əz jə wəɾ əloʊn."

"She is right, Rand," Loial said, rising. "I can see better by moonlight than you. With my eyes, we may not need to go as close as you would alone."

"vɛɹi wɛl." ɹænd stʃɹoʊɾ oʊvɝ tə hɪz sɔɹɾ ən bʌkəld ɪɾ əɾ ɪz weɪst. baʊ ən kwɪvɝ i lɛft wɛɹ ðeɪ leɪ; ə baʊ wɑz nɑɾ ə mʌtʃ jus ɪn ðə dɑɹk, ən i ɪntɛndəd tə lʊk, nɑt faɪt. "hʊɹɪn, ʃoʊ mi ðɪs faɪɝ."

"Very well." Rand strode over to his sword and buckled it at his waist. Bow and quiver he left where they lay; a bow was not of much use in the dark, and he intended to look, not fight. "Hurin, show me this fire."

ðə snɪfɝ lɛɾ ɪm skɹæmbəlɪŋ ʌp ðə sloʊp tə ði aʊtkɹɑp, laɪk ə hjudʒ stoʊn θʌm θɹʌst aʊɾ ə ðə maʊntən. ðə faɪɝ wɑz oʊnli ə spɛk - hi mɪst ɪt ðə fɝs taɪm hʊɹɪn pɔɪntəd. huɛvɝ hæd meɪɾ ɪt dɪd nɑt min fəɹ ɪt tə bi sin. hi fɪkst ɪɾ ɪn ɪz hɛd.

The sniffer led him scrambling up the slope to the outcrop, like a huge stone thumb thrust out of the mountain. The fire was only a speck - he missed it the first time Hurin pointed. Whoever had made it did not mean for it to be seen. He fixed it in his head.

baɪ ðə taɪm ðeɪ ɹɪtɝn tə ðə kæmp, lɔɪəl hæd sæɾəld ɹɛɾ ən ɪz oʊn hɔɹs. əz ɹænd klaɪm tə ðə beɪz bæk, səlin kɑɾ ɪz hænd. "ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə ɡlɔɹi," ʃi sɛd sɔfli. "ɹɪmɛmbɝ." ðə ʃɝt sim tə fɪɾ əɹ bɛɾɝ ðən i ɹɪkɔld, moʊldɪŋ ɪtsɛlf tə hɝ fɔɹm.

By the time they returned to the camp, Loial had saddled Red and his own horse. As Rand climbed to the bay's back, Selene caught his hand. "Remember the glory," she said softly. "Remember." The shirt seemed to fit her better than he recalled, molding itself to her form.

hi dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ ən tʊk ɪz hæn bæk. "ɡɑɹɾ əɹ wɪð jəɹ laɪf, hʊɹɪn. lɔɪəl?" hi hild ɹɛdz flæŋks dʒɛnli. ði oʊɡiɝz bɪɡ maʊn plɑɾəd əlɔŋ bɪhaɪnd.

He drew a deep breath and took his hand back. "Guard her with your life, Hurin. Loial?" He heeled Red's flanks gently. The Ogier's big mount plodded along behind.

ðeɪ dɪd nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə muv kwɪkli. naɪt ʃɹaʊɾɪd ðə maʊntənsaɪd, ən mun-kæst ʃædoʊz meɪd fʊɾɪŋ ənsɝɾən. ɹænd kəd nɑt si ðə faɪɝ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ - noʊ daʊɾ ɪt wɑz bɛɾɝ hɪɾən fɹəm aɪz ɑn ðə seɪm lɛvəl - bʌɾ i hæɾ ɪts loʊkeɪʃən ɪn ɪz maɪnd. fəɹ sʌmwʌn u hæd lɝn tə hʌn ɪn ðə tæŋɡəl ə ðə wɛstwʊd, ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, faɪndɪŋ ðə faɪɝ wəd bi noʊ ɡɹeɪt dɪfəkəlti. ən wʌt ðɛn? səlinz feɪs lum bɪfɔɹ hɪm. haʊ pɹaʊɾ əl bi tə stæn bɪsaɪɾ ɪm u hoʊlz ðə hɔɹn.

They did not try to move quickly. Night shrouded the mountainside, and moon-cast shadows made footing uncertain. Rand could not see the fire any longer - no doubt it was better hidden from eyes on the same level - but he had its location in his mind. For someone who had learned to hunt in the tangle of the Westwood, in the Two Rivers, finding the fire would be no great difficulty. And what then? Selene's face loomed before him. How proud I'll be to stand beside him who holds the Horn.

"lɔɪəl," hi sɛd sʌɾənli, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə klɪɹ ɪz θɔts, "wʌts ðɪs ælɑntɪn ʃi kɔlz ju?"

"Loial," he said suddenly, trying to clear his thoughts, "what's this alantin she calls you?"

"ɪts ði oʊl tʌŋ, ɹænd." ði oʊɡiɝz hɔɹs pɪkt ɪts weɪ ənsɝteɪnli, bʌɾ i ɡaɪɾəd ɪɾ ɔlmoʊst əz ʃʊɹli əz ɪf ɪt wɝ deɪlaɪt. "ɪt minz bɹʌðɝ, ən ɪz ʃɔɹt fəɹ tiə ɑvɛn ælɑntɪn. bɹʌðɝ tə ðə tʃɹiz. tʃɹibɹəðɝ. ɪts vɛɹi fɔɹməl, bʌt ðɛn, aɪv hɝd ðə kɛɹhinɪn ɑɹ fɔɹməl. ðə noʊbəl haʊsəz ɑɹ, ət list. ðə kɑmən pipəl aɪ sɔ ðəɹ wɝ nɑt vɛɹi fɔɹməl əɾ ɔl."

"It's the Old Tongue, Rand." The Ogier's horse picked its way uncertainly, but he guided it almost as surely as if it were daylight. "It means Brother, and is short for tia avende alantin. Brother to the Trees. Treebrother. It is very formal, but then, I've heard the Cairhienin are formal. The noble Houses are, at least. The common people I saw there were not very formal at all."

ɹænd fɹaʊnd. ə ʃɛpɝd wəd nɑt bi vɛɹi æksɛptəbəl tə ə fɔɹməl kɛɹhinɪn noʊbəl haʊs. laɪt, mæts ɹaɪɾ əbaʊt ju. jəɹ kɹeɪzi, ən wɪð ə bɪɡ hɛd tə but. bʌɾ ɪf aɪ kəd mɛɹi. . . .

Rand frowned. A shepherd would not be very acceptable to a formal Cairhienin noble House. Light, Mat's right about you. You're crazy, and with a big head to boot. But if I could marry. . . .

hi wɪʃt i kəd stɑp θɪŋkɪŋ, ən bɪfɔɹ i ɹilaɪzd ɪt, ðə vɔɪd hæd fɔɹmd wɪðɪn hɪm, meɪkɪŋ θɔts dɪstən θɪŋz, əz ɪf pɑɹɾ ə sʌmwʌn ɛls. seɪɾɪn ʃoʊn ət hɪm, bɛkən tə hɪm. hi ɡɹɪɾɪd ɪz tiθ ən ɪɡnɔɹɾ ɪt; ɪt wɑz laɪk ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ə bɝnɪŋ koʊl ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz hɛd, bʌɾ ət list i kəd hoʊld ɪɾ ət beɪ. bɛɹli. hi ɔlmoʊs lɛf ðə vɔɪd, bʌt ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz wɝ aʊt ðəɹ ɪn ðə naɪt, ən kloʊsɝ, naʊ. ən ðə tʃɹɑləks. hi niɾəd ði ɛmptinəs, niɾəd ivən ði ənizi kɑm ə ðə vɔɪd. aɪ doʊn əv tə tʌtʃ ɪt. aɪ doʊnt.

He wished he could stop thinking, and before he realized it, the void had formed within him, making thoughts distant things, as if part of someone else. Saidin shone at him, beckoned to him. He gritted his teeth and ignored it; it was like ignoring a burning coal inside his head, but at least he could hold it at bay. Barely. He almost left the void, but the Darkfriends were out there in the night, and closer, now. And the Trollocs. He needed the emptiness, needed even the uneasy calm of the void. I don't have to touch it. I don't.

æftɝ ə taɪm, hi ɹeɪn ɪn ɹɛd. ðeɪ stʊɾ ət ðə beɪs ʌv ə hɪl, ðə waɪd-skæɾɝd tʃɹiz ɑn ɪts sloʊps blæk ɪn ðə naɪt. "aɪ θɪŋk wi mʌs bi kloʊs baɪ naʊ," hi sɛd sɔfli. "bɛst wi ɡoʊ ðə ɹɛst ə ðə weɪ ɑn fʊt." hi slɪd fɹəm ðə sæɾəl ən taɪd ðə beɪz ɹeɪnz tə ə bɹæntʃ.

After a time, he reined in Red. They stood at the base of a hill, the wide-scattered trees on its slopes black in the night. "I think we must be close by now," he said softly. "Best we go the rest of the way on foot." He slid from the saddle and tied the bay's reins to a branch.

"ɑɹ jə ɔl ɹaɪt?" lɔɪəl wɪspɝd, klaɪmɪŋ daʊn. "ju saʊn ɑd."

"Are you all right?" Loial whispered, climbing down. "You sound odd."

"aɪm faɪn." hɪz vɔɪs saʊndəd taɪt, hi ɹilaɪzd. stʃɹɛtʃt. seɪɾɪn kɔl tə hɪm. noʊ! "bi kɛɹfəl. aɪ kæn bi ʃʊɹ ɪɡzækli haʊ fɑɹ ɪɾ ɪz, bʌt ðət faɪɝ ʃəd bi sʌmwɛɹ dʒʌst əhɛɾ ʌv ʌs. ɑn ðə hɪltɑp, aɪ θɪŋk." ði oʊɡiɝ nɑɾəd.

"I'm fine." His voice sounded tight, he realized. Stretched. Saidin called to him. No! "Be careful. I can't be sure exactly how far it is, but that fire should be somewhere just ahead of us. On the hilltop, I think." The Ogier nodded.

sloʊli ɹænd stoʊl fɹəm tʃɹi tə tʃɹi, pleɪsɪŋ itʃ fʊt kɛɹfəli, hoʊldɪŋ ɪz sɔɹd taɪt soʊ ɪt dɪd nɑt klæɾɝ əɡɛnst ə tʃɹi tʃɹʌŋk. hi wɑz ɡɹeɪtfəl fəɹ ðə læk ʌv ʌndɝɡɹoʊθ. lɔɪəl fɑloʊd laɪk ə bɪɡ ʃædoʊ; ɹænd kəd nɑt si mʌtʃ mɔɹ ə hɪm ðən ðæt. ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɑz munʃæɾoʊz ən dɑɹknəs.

Slowly Rand stole from tree to tree, placing each foot carefully, holding his sword tight so it did not clatter against a tree trunk. He was grateful for the lack of undergrowth. Loial followed like a big shadow; Rand could not see much more of him than that. Everything was moonshadows and darkness.

sʌɾənli səm tʃɹɪk ə ðə munlaɪt ɹizɑlv ðə ʃædoʊz əhɛɾ ə hɪm, ən i fɹoʊz, tʌtʃɪŋ ðə ɹʌf boʊl ʌv ə lɛðɝlif. dɪm maʊnz ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪkeɪm mɛn ɹæpt ɪn blæŋkəts, ən əpɑɹt fɹəm əm ə ɡɹup ə lɑɹdʒɝ maʊnz. slipɪŋ tʃɹɑləks. ðeɪ hæd daʊs ðə faɪɝ. wʌn munbim, muvɪŋ θɹu ðə bɹæntʃəz, kɑɾ ə ʃaɪn ʌv ɡoʊld ən sɪlvɝ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, hæfweɪ bɪtwin ðə tu ɡɹups. ðə munlaɪt sim tə bɹaɪɾən; fəɹ ən ɪnstən i kəd si klɪɹli. ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ə slipɪŋ mæn leɪ kloʊs baɪ tə ðə ɡlim, bʌt ðət wɑz nɑt wʌt hɛld ɪz aɪ. ðə tʃɛst. ðə hɔɹn. ən sʌmθɪŋ ətɑp ɪt, ə pɔɪn ə ɹɛd flæʃɪŋ ɪn ðə munbim. ðə dæɡɝ! waɪ wəd feɪn pʊt . . . ?

Suddenly some trick of the moonlight resolved the shadows ahead of him, and he froze, touching the rough bole of a leatherleaf. Dim mounds on the ground became men wrapped in blankets, and apart from them a group of larger mounds. Sleeping Trollocs. They had doused the fire. One moonbeam, moving through the branches, caught a shine of gold and silver on the ground, halfway between the two groups. The moonlight seemed to brighten; for an instant he could see clearly. The shape of a sleeping man lay close by to the gleam, but that was not what held his eye. The chest. The Horn. And something atop it, a point of red flashing in the moonbeam. The dagger! Why would Fain put . . . ?

lɔɪəlz hjudʒ hæn sɛɾəld oʊvɝ ɹændz maʊθ, ən ə ɡʊd pɑɹɾ ə hɪz feɪs bɪsaɪdz. hi twɪstəd tə lʊk ət ði oʊɡiɝ. lɔɪəl pɔɪntəɾ ɔf tə hɪz ɹaɪt, sloʊli, əz ɪf moʊʃən maɪɾ ətʃɹækt ətɛnʃən.

Loial's huge hand settled over Rand's mouth, and a good part of his face besides. He twisted to look at the Ogier. Loial pointed off to his right, slowly, as if motion might attract attention.

ət fɝst ɹænd kəd nɑt si ɛniθɪŋ, ðən ə ʃædoʊ muvd, nɑt tɛn peɪsɪz əweɪ. ə tɔl, bʌlki ʃædoʊ, ən snaʊɾəd. ɹændz bɹɛθ kɑt. eɪ tʃɹɑlɑk. ɪt lɪftəɾ ɪts snaʊɾ əz ɪf snɪfɪŋ. səm ə ðɛm hʌntəd baɪ sɛnt.

At first Rand could not see anything, then a shadow moved, not ten paces away. A tall, bulky shadow, and snouted. Rand's breath caught. A Trolloc. It lifted its snout as if sniffing. Some of them hunted by scent.

fəɹ ən ɪnstən ðə vɔɪd weɪvɝd. sʌmwʌn stɝɾ ɪn ðə dɑɹkfɹɛn kæmp, ən ðə tʃɹɑlɑk tɝn tə pɪɹ ðət weɪ.

For an instant the void wavered. Someone stirred in the Darkfriend camp, and the Trolloc turned to peer that way.

ɹænd fɹoʊz, lɛɾɪŋ ðə kɑm ʌv ɛmptinəs ɛnvəloʊp hɪm. hɪz hænd wɑz ɑn ɪz sɔɹd, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ʌv ɪt. ðə vɔɪd wɑz ɔl. wʌtɛvɝ hæpənd, hæpənd. hi wɑtʃt ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɪθaʊt blɪŋkɪŋ.

Rand froze, letting the calm of emptiness envelope him. His hand was on his sword, but he did not think of it. The void was all. Whatever happened, happened. He watched the Trolloc without blinking.

ə moʊmən lɔŋɡɝ ðə snaʊɾəd ʃædoʊ wɑtʃt ðə dɑɹkfɹɛn kæmp, ðɛn, əz ɪf sæɾəsfaɪd, foʊldəɾ ɪtsɛlf daʊn bɪsaɪɾ ə tʃɹi. ɔlmoʊst ɪmiɾiətli ə loʊ saʊnd, laɪk kɔɹs klɔθ ɹɪpɪŋ, dʒɹɪftəd fɹəm ɪt.

A moment longer the snouted shadow watched the Darkfriend camp, then, as if satisfied, folded itself down beside a tree. Almost immediately a low sound, like coarse cloth ripping, drifted from it.

lɔɪəl pʊɾ ɪz maʊθ kloʊs tə ɹændz ɪɹ. "ɪts əslip," hi wɪspɝɾ ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli.

Loial put his mouth close to Rand's ear. "It's asleep," he whispered incredulously.

ɹænd nɑɾəd. tæm hæd toʊld ɪm tʃɹɑləks wɝ leɪzi, æp tə ɡɪv ʌp ɛni tæsk bʌt kɪlɪŋ ənlɛs fɪɹ kɛpt əm tə ɪt. hi tɝn bæk tə ðə kæmp.

Rand nodded. Tam had told him Trollocs were lazy, apt to give up any task but killing unless fear kept them to it. He turned back to the camp.

ɔl wɑz stɪl ən kwaɪət ðəɹ əɡɛn. ðə munbim noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ʃoʊn ɑn ðə tʃɛst, bʌɾ i nu naʊ wɪtʃ ʃædoʊ ɪt wɑz. hi kəd si ɪɾ ɪn ɪz maɪnd, floʊɾɪŋ bɪɑn ðə vɔɪd, ɡlɪɾɝɪŋ ɡoʊldən, tʃeɪst wɪð sɪlvɝ, ɪn ðə ɡloʊ ʌv seɪɾɪn. ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ ən ðə dæɡɝ mæt niɾəd, boʊθ ɔlmoʊst wɪðɪn ɹitʃ ə hɪz hænd. səlinz feɪs dʒɹɪftəd wɪð ðə tʃɛst. ðeɪ kəd fɑloʊ feɪnz pɑɹɾi ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ, ən weɪɾ əntɪl ɪŋtʃɹ dʒɔɪn ðɛm. ɪf ɪŋtʃɹ dɪd kʌm, ɪf i stɪl fɑloʊd ðə tʃɹeɪl wɪθaʊɾ ɪz snɪfɝ. noʊ, ðəɹ wəd nɛvɝ bi ə bɛɾɝ tʃæns. ɔl wɪðɪn ɹitʃ ə hɪz hænd. səlin wɑz weɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə maʊntən.

All was still and quiet there again. The moonbeam no longer shone on the chest, but he knew now which shadow it was. He could see it in his mind, floating beyond the void, glittering golden, chased with silver, in the glow of saidin. The Horn of Valere and the dagger Mat needed, both almost within reach of his hand. Selene's face drifted with the chest. They could follow Fain's party in the morning, and wait until Ingtar joined them. If Ingtar did come, if he still followed the trail without his sniffer. No, there would never be a better chance. All within reach of his hand. Selene was waiting on the mountain.

moʊʃənɪŋ fəɹ lɔɪəl tə fɑloʊ, ɹænd dʒɹɑp tə hɪz bɛli ən kɹɔl təwɔɹd ðə tʃɛst. hi hɝd ði oʊɡiɝz mʌfəld ɡæsp, bʌɾ ɪz aɪz wɝ fɪkst ɑn ðət wʌn ʃæɾoʊd maʊn əhɛd.

Motioning for Loial to follow, Rand dropped to his belly and crawled toward the chest. He heard the Ogier's muffled gasp, but his eyes were fixed on that one shadowed mound ahead.

dɑɹkfɹɛnz ən tʃɹɑləks leɪ tə lɛft ən ɹaɪɾ ə hɪm, bʌt wʌns i hæd sin tæm stɔk kloʊs ɪnʌf tə ə dɪɹ tə pʊɾ ɪz hæn ɑn ɪts flæŋk bɪfɔɹ ði ænəməl baʊndəɾ ɔf; hi hæd tʃɹaɪd tə lɝn fɹəm tæm. mædnəs! ðə θɔt flu baɪ dɪmli, ɔlmoʊst aʊɾ ə ɹitʃ. ðɪs ɪz mædnəs! jə - ɑɹ - ɡoʊɪŋ - mæd! dɪm θɔts; sʌmwʌn ɛlsəz θɔts.

Darkfriends and Trollocs lay to left and right of him, but once he had seen Tam stalk close enough to a deer to put his hand on its flank before the animal bounded off; he had tried to learn from Tam. Madness! The thought flew by dimly, almost out of reach. This is madness! You - are - going - mad! Dim thoughts; someone else's thoughts.

sloʊli, saɪlənli, hi slaɪðɝd tə ðət wʌn spɛʃəl ʃædoʊ, ən pʊɾ aʊɾ ə hænd. ɔɹneɪt tʃɹeɪsɝiz wɝkt ɪn ɡoʊl mɛɾ ɪz tʌtʃ. ɪt wɑz ðə tʃɛs ðət hɛl ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ. hɪz hæn tʌtʃt sʌmθɪŋ ɛls, ɑn ðə lɪd. ðə dæɡɝ, bɛɹ-bleɪɾɪd. ɪn ðə dɑɹk, hɪz aɪz waɪɾənd. ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ wʌɾ ɪt hæd dʌn tə mæt, hi dʒɝk bæk, ðə vɔɪd ʃɪftɪŋ wɪð ɪz ædʒəteɪʃən.

Slowly, silently, he slithered to that one special shadow, and put out a hand. Ornate traceries worked in gold met his touch. It was the chest that held the Horn of Valere. His hand touched something else, on the lid. The dagger, bare-bladed. In the dark, his eyes widened. Remembering what it had done to Mat, he jerked back, the void shifting with his agitation.

ðə mæn slipɪŋ nɪɹbaɪ - noʊ mɔɹ ðən tu peɪsɪz fɹəm ðə tʃɛst; noʊ wʌn ɛls leɪ soʊ kloʊs baɪ spænz - ɡɹoʊn ɪn ɪz slip ən θɹæʃt əɾ ɪz blæŋkəts. ɹænd əlaʊd ðə vɔɪd tə swip θɔɾ ən fɪɹ əweɪ. mɝmɝɪŋ ənizəli ɪn ɪz slip, ðə mæn stɪld.

The man sleeping nearby - no more than two paces from the chest; no one else lay so close by spans - groaned in his sleep and thrashed at his blankets. Rand allowed the void to sweep thought and fear away. Murmuring uneasily in his sleep, the man stilled.

ɹænd lɛɾ ɪz hænd ɡoʊ bæk tə ðə dæɡɝ, nɑt kwaɪt tʌtʃɪŋ ɪt. ɪt hæd nɑt hɑɹmd mæt ɪn ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ. nɑt mʌtʃ, ət list; nɑt kwɪkli. ɪn wʌn swɪf moʊʃən i lɪftəd ðə dæɡɝ, stʌk ɪt bɪhaɪn ɪz bɛlt, ən pʊld ɪz hæn əweɪ, əz ɪf ɪt maɪt hɛlp tə mɪnəmaɪz ðə taɪm ɪt tʌtʃt ɪz bɛɹ skɪn. pɝhæps ɪt wʊd, ən mæt wəd daɪ wɪθaʊt ðə dæɡɝ. hi kəd fil ɪt ðɛɹ, ɔlmoʊst ə weɪt pʊlɪŋ ɪm daʊn, pɹɛsɪŋ əɡɛns hɪm. bʌɾ ɪn ðə vɔɪd sɛnseɪʃən wɑz əz dɪstən əz θɔt, ən ðə fil ə ðə dæɡɝ feɪɾəd kwɪkli tə sʌmθɪŋ i wɑz juz tə.

Rand let his hand go back to the dagger, not quite touching it. It had not harmed Mat in the beginning. Not much, at least; not quickly. In one swift motion he lifted the dagger, stuck it behind his belt, and pulled his hand away, as if it might help to minimize the time it touched his bare skin. Perhaps it would, and Mat would die without the dagger. He could feel it there, almost a weight pulling him down, pressing against him. But in the void sensation was as distant as thought, and the feel of the dagger faded quickly to something he was used to.

hi weɪstəɾ oʊnli ə moʊmən mɔɹ stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə ʃædoʊ-ɹæp tʃɛst - ðə hɔɹn hæd tə bi ɪnsaɪd, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt noʊ haʊ tə oʊpən ɪɾ ən i kəd nɑt lɪft ɪt baɪ hɪmsɛlf - ðən i lʊkt ɝaʊn fəɹ lɔɪəl. hi faʊn ði oʊɡiɝ kɹaʊtʃt nɑt fɑɹ bɪhaɪn hɪm, mæsɪv hɛd swɪvəlɪŋ əz i pɪɹd bæk ən fɔɹθ fɹəm slipɪŋ hjumən dɑɹkfɹɛnz tə slipɪŋ tʃɹɑləks. ivən ɪn ðə naɪɾ ɪt wɑz pleɪn lɔɪəlz aɪz wɝ əz waɪɾ əz ðeɪ kəd ɡoʊ; ðeɪ lʊkt əz bɪɡ əz sɔsɝz ɪn ðə laɪɾ ə ðə mun. ɹænd ɹitʃt aʊɾ ən tʊk lɔɪəlz hænd.

He wasted only a moment more staring at the shadow-wrapped chest - the Horn had to be inside, but he did not know how to open it and he could not lift it by himself - then he looked around for Loial. He found the Ogier crouched not far behind him, massive head swiveling as he peered back and forth from sleeping human Darkfriends to sleeping Trollocs. Even in the night it was plain Loial's eyes were as wide as they could go; they looked as big as saucers in the light of the moon. Rand reached out and took Loial's hand.

ði oʊɡiɝ ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ ən ɡæspt. ɹænd pʊɾ ə fɪŋɡɝ əkɹɔs ɪz lɪps, sɛt lɔɪəlz hæn ɑn ðə tʃɛst, ən mɪm lɪftɪŋ. fəɹ ə taɪm - ɪt sim fɝɛvɝ, ɪn ðə naɪt, wɪð dɑɹkfɹɛnz ən tʃɹɑləks ɔl ɝaʊnd; ɪt kəd nɑɾ əv bɪn mɔɹ ðən hɑɹtbits - lɔɪəl stɛɹd. ðɛn, sloʊli, hi pʊɾ ɪz ɑɹmz ɝaʊn ðə ɡoʊldən tʃɛst ən stʊd. hi meɪɾ ɪt sim ɛfɝtləs.

The Ogier gave a start and gasped. Rand put a finger across his lips, set Loial's hand on the chest, and mimed lifting. For a time - it seemed forever, in the night, with Darkfriends and Trollocs all around; it could not have been more than heartbeats - Loial stared. Then, slowly, he put his arms around the golden chest and stood. He made it seem effortless.

ɛvɝ soʊ kɛɹfəli, ivən mɔɹ kɛɹfəli ðən i hæd kʌm ɪn, ɹænd bɪɡæn tə wɔk aʊɾ ə ðə kæmp, bɪhaɪn lɔɪəl ən ðə tʃɛst. boʊθ hænz ɑn ɪz sɔɹd, hi wɑtʃt ðə slipɪŋ dɑɹkfɹɛnz, ðə stɪl ʃeɪps ə ðə tʃɹɑləks. ɔl ðoʊz ʃæɾoʊd fɪɡjɝz bɪɡæn tə bi swɑloʊd dipɝ ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs əz ðeɪ dʒɹu əweɪ. ɔlmoʊs fɹi. wiv dʌn ɪt!

Ever so carefully, even more carefully than he had come in, Rand began to walk out of the camp, behind Loial and the chest. Both hands on his sword, he watched the sleeping Darkfriends, the still shapes of the Trollocs. All those shadowed figures began to be swallowed deeper in the darkness as they drew away. Almost free. We've done it!

ðə mæn u hæd bɪn slipɪŋ nɪɹ ðə tʃɛst sʌɾənli sæɾ ʌp wɪð ə stʃɹæŋɡəl jɛl, ðən lɛp tə hɪz fit. "ɪts ɡɔn! weɪk, jə fɪlθ! ɪts ɡuun!" feɪnz vɔɪs; ivən ɪn ðə vɔɪd ɹænd ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd ɪt. ði ʌðɝz skɹæmbəld ɪɹɛkt, dɑɹkfɹɛnz ən tʃɹɑləks, kɔlɪŋ tə noʊ wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ, ɡɹoʊlɪŋ ən snɑɹlɪŋ. feɪnz vɔɪs ɹoʊz tə ə haʊl. "aɪ noʊ ɪts ju, ælθɹ! jəɹ haɪɾɪŋ fɹəm mi, bʌɾ aɪ noʊ jə ɑɹ aʊt ðɛɹ! faɪn hɪm! faɪn hɪm! æltuʊʊɹ!" mɛn ən tʃɹɑləks skæɾɝd ɪn ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən.

The man who had been sleeping near the chest suddenly sat up with a strangled yell, then leaped to his feet. "It's gone! Wake, you filth! It's gooonnne!" Fain's voice; even in the void Rand recognized it. The others scrambled erect, Darkfriends and Trollocs, calling to know what was happening, growling and snarling. Fain's voice rose to a howl. "I know it is you, al'Thor! You're hiding from me, but I know you are out there! Find him! Find him! Al'Thoooor!" Men and Trollocs scattered in every direction.

ɹæpt ɪn ɛmptinəs, ɹænd kɛp muvɪŋ. ɔlmoʊs fɝɡɑɾən ɪn ɛntɝɪŋ ðə kæmp, seɪɾɪn pʌlsd ət hɪm.

Wrapped in emptiness, Rand kept moving. Almost forgotten in entering the camp, saidin pulsed at him.

"hi kænɑt si ʌs," lɔɪəl wɪspɝd loʊ. "wʌns wi ɹitʃ ðə hɔɹsəz - "

"He cannot see us," Loial whispered low. "Once we reach the horses - "

eɪ tʃɹɑlɑk lɛpt aʊɾ ə ðə dɑɹk ət ðɛm, kɹuəl iɡəlz bik ɪn ə mænz feɪs wɛɹ maʊθ ən noʊz ʃəɾ əv bɪn, saɪð-laɪk sɔɹɾ ɔlɹɛɾi wɪslɪŋ θɹu ði ɛɹ.

A Trolloc leaped out of the dark at them, cruel eagle's beak in a man's face where mouth and nose should have been, scythe-like sword already whistling through the air.

ɹænd muvd wɪθaʊt θɔt. hi wɑz wʌn wɪð ðə bleɪd. kæt dænsəz ɑn ðə wɔl. ðə tʃɹɑlɑk skɹimd əz ɪt fɛl, skɹimd əɡɛn əz ɪt daɪd.

Rand moved without thought. He was one with the blade. Cat Dances on the Wall. The Trolloc screamed as it fell, screamed again as it died.

"ɹʌn, lɔɪəl!" ɹænd kəmændəd. seɪɾɪn kɔl tə hɪm. "ɹʌn!"

"Run, Loial!" Rand commanded. Saidin called to him. "Run!"

hi wɑz dɪmli əwɛɹ ə lɔɪəl lʌmbɝɪŋ tə ən ɑkwɝd ɡæləp, bʌɾ ənʌðɝ tʃɹɑlɑk lum fɹəm ðə naɪt, bɔɹ-snaʊɾəd ən tʌskt, spaɪkt æks ɹeɪzd. smuðli ɹænd ɡlaɪɾɪd bɪtwin tʃɹɑlɑk ən oʊɡiɝ; lɔɪəl mʌst ɡɛt ðə hɔɹn əweɪ. hɛɾ ən ʃoʊldɝz tɔlɝ ðən ɹænd, hæf əɡɛn əz waɪd, ðə tʃɹɑlɑk keɪm əɾ ɪm wɪð ə saɪlən snɑɹl. ðə kɔɹɾiɝ tæps ɪz fæn. noʊ skɹim, ðɪs taɪm. hi wɔk bækwɝdz æftɝ lɔɪəl, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə naɪt. seɪɾɪn sæŋ tə hɪm, sətʃ ə swit sɔŋ. ðə paʊɝ kəd bɝn əm ɔl, bɝn feɪn ən ɔl ðə ɹɛs tə sɪndɝz. noʊ!

He was dimly aware of Loial lumbering to an awkward gallop, but another Trolloc loomed from the night, boar-snouted and tusked, spiked axe raised. Smoothly Rand glided between Trolloc and Ogier; Loial must get the Horn away. Head and shoulders taller than Rand, half again as wide, the Trolloc came at him with a silent snarl. The Courtier Taps His Fan. No scream, this time. He walked backwards after Loial, watching the night. Saidin sang to him, such a sweet song. The Power could burn them all, burn Fain and all the rest to cinders. No!

tu mɔɹ tʃɹɑləks, wʊlf ən ɹæm, ɡlimɪŋ tiθ ən kɝlɪŋ hɔɹnz. lɪzɝɾ ɪn ðə θɔɹnbʊʃ. hi ɹoʊz smuðli fɹəm wʌn ni əz ðə sɛkən tɑpəld, hɔɹnz ɔlmoʊs bɹʌʃɪŋ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. ðə sɔŋ ə seɪɾɪn kɝɛst ɪm wɪð sɪdʌkʃən, pʊld ɪm wɪð ə θaʊzən sɪlkən stʃɹɪŋz. bɝn əm ɔl wɪð ðə paʊɝ. noʊ. noʊ! bɛɾɝ dɛd ðən ðæt. ɪf aɪ wɝ dɛd, ɪt wəd bi dʌn wɪð.

Two more Trollocs, wolf and ram, gleaming teeth and curling horns. Lizard in the Thornbush. He rose smoothly from one knee as the second toppled, horns almost brushing his shoulder. The song of saidin caressed him with seduction, pulled him with a thousand silken strings. Burn them all with the Power. No. No! Better dead than that. If I were dead, it would be done with.

ə nɑɾ ə tʃɹɑləks keɪm ɪndə saɪt, hʌntɪŋ ənsɝteɪnli. θɹi ʌv ðɛm, fɔɹ. sʌɾənli wʌn pɔɪntəd tə ɹænd ən ɹeɪzd ə haʊl ðə ɹɛst ænsɝɾ əz ðeɪ tʃɑɹdʒd.

A knot of Trollocs came into sight, hunting uncertainly. Three of them, four. Suddenly one pointed to Rand and raised a howl the rest answered as they charged.

"lɛɾ ɪt bi dʌn wɪð!" ɹænd ʃaʊɾəd, ən lɛp tə mit ðɛm.

"Let it be done with!" Rand shouted, and leaped to meet them.

fəɹ ən ɪnstən sɝpɹaɪz sloʊd ðɛm, ðən ðeɪ keɪm ɑn wɪð ɡʌɾɝəl kɹaɪz ɡlifəl, blʌdθɝsti, sɔɹdz ən æksiz ɹeɪzd. hi dænst əmʌŋ əm tə ðə sɔŋ ə seɪɾɪn. hʌmɪŋbɝd kɪsəz ðə hʌniɹoʊz. soʊ kʌnɪŋ ðət sɔŋ, fɪlɪŋ hɪm. kæɾ ɑn hɑt sænd. ðə sɔɹd simd əlaɪv ɪn ɪz hænz əz ɪt hæd nɛvɝ bɪn bɪfɔɹ, ən i fɔɾ əz ɪf ə hɛɹən-mɑɹk bleɪd kəd kip seɪɾɪn fɹəm hɪm. ðə hɛɹən spɹɛdz ɪts wɪŋz.

For an instant surprise slowed them, then they came on with guttural cries gleeful, bloodthirsty, swords and axes raised. He danced among them to the song of saidin. Hummingbird Kisses the Honeyrose. So cunning that song, filling him. Cat on Hot Sand. The sword seemed alive in his hands as it had never been before, and he fought as if a heron-mark blade could keep saidin from him. The Heron Spreads Its Wings.

ɹænd stɛɹɾ ət ðə moʊʃənləs ʃeɪps ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn ɝaʊn hɪm. "bɛɾɝ tə bi dɛd," hi mɝmɝd. hi ɹeɪzd ɪz aɪz, bæk ʌp ðə hɪl təwɔɹd wɛɹ ðə kæmp leɪ. feɪn wɑz ðɛɹ, ən dɑɹkfɹɛnz, ən mɔɹ tʃɹɑləks. tu mɛni tə faɪt. tu mɛni tə feɪs ən laɪv. hi tʊk ə stɛp ðət weɪ. ənʌðɝ.

Rand stared at the motionless shapes on the ground around him. "Better to be dead," he murmured. He raised his eyes, back up the hill toward where the camp lay. Fain was there, and Darkfriends, and more Trollocs. Too many to fight. Too many to face and live. He took a step that way. Another.

"ɹænd, kʌm ɑn!" lɔɪəlz ɝdʒənt, wɪspɝd kɔl dʒɹɪftəd θɹu ði ɛmptinəs tə hɪm. "fɔɹ laɪf ən ðə laɪt, ɹænd, kʌm ɑn!"

"Rand, come on!" Loial's urgent, whispered call drifted through the emptiness to him. "For life and the Light, Rand, come on!"

kɛɹfəli, ɹænd bɛn tə waɪp ɪz bleɪɾ ɑn ə tʃɹɑlɑks koʊt. ðɛn, əz fɔɹməli əz ɪf læn wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ ɪm tʃɹeɪn, hi ʃiðd ɪt.

Carefully, Rand bent to wipe his blade on a Trolloc's coat. Then, as formally as if Lan were watching him train, he sheathed it.

"ɹænd!"

"Rand!"

əz ðoʊ hi nu ʌv noʊ ɝdʒənsi, ɹænd dʒɔɪn lɔɪəl baɪ ðə hɔɹsəz. ði oʊɡiɝ wɑz taɪɪŋ ðə ɡoʊldən tʃɛst ətɑp ɪz sæɾəl wɪð stʃɹæps fɹəm ɪz sæɾəlbæɡz. hɪz kloʊk wɑz stʌft ʌndɝniθ tə hɛlp bæləns ðə tʃɛst ɑn ðə ɹaʊndəd sæɾəl sit.

As though he knew of no urgency, Rand joined Loial by the horses. The Ogier was tying the golden chest atop his saddle with straps from his saddlebags. His cloak was stuffed underneath to help balance the chest on the rounded saddle seat.

seɪɾɪn sæŋ noʊ mɔɹ. ɪt wɑz ðɛɹ, ðət stʌmək-tɝnɪŋ ɡloʊ, bʌɾ ɪt hɛl bæk əz ɪf i tʃɹuli hæd fɔɾ ɪɾ ɔf. wʌndɝɪŋli, hi lɛt ðə vɔɪd vænɪʃ. "aɪ θɪŋk aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ mæd," hi sɛd. sʌɾənli ɹilaɪzɪŋ wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ, hi pɪɹd bæk ðə weɪ ðeɪ hæd kʌm. ʃaʊts ən haʊlz keɪm fɹəm hæf ə dʌzən dɪfɹən dɝɛkʃənz; saɪnz ə sɝtʃ, bʌt nʌn ə pɝsut. jɛt. hi swʌŋ ʌp ɑntu ɹɛdz bæk.

Saidin sang no more. It was there, that stomach-turning glow, but it held back as if he truly had fought it off. Wonderingly, he let the void vanish. "I think I am going mad," he said. Suddenly realizing where they were, he peered back the way they had come. Shouts and howls came from half a dozen different directions; signs of search, but none of pursuit. Yet. He swung up onto Red's back.

"səmtaɪmz aɪ də nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn hæf ʌv wʌt jə seɪ," lɔɪəl sɛd. "ɪf jə mʌst ɡoʊ mæd, kəɾ ɪɾ ət list weɪɾ əntɪl wəɹ bæk wɪð ðə leɪɾi səlin ən hʊɹɪn?"

"Sometimes I do not understand half of what you say," Loial said. "If you must go mad, could it at least wait until we are back with the Lady Selene and Hurin?"

"haʊ ɑɹ jə gɑnə ɹaɪd wɪð ðəɾ ɪn jəɹ sæɾəl?"

"How are you going to ride with that in your saddle?"

"aɪ wɪl ɹʌn!" ði oʊɡiɝ suɾəd ɪz wɝdz baɪ bɹeɪkɪŋ ɪndə ə kwɪk tʃɹɑt, pʊlɪŋ ɪz hɔɹs bɪhaɪn ɪm baɪ ðə ɹeɪnz. ɹænd fɑloʊd.

"I will run!" The Ogier suited his words by breaking into a quick trot, pulling his horse behind him by the reins. Rand followed.

ðə peɪs lɔɪəl sɛt wɑz əz fæst əz ə hɔɹs kəd tʃɹɑt. ɹænd wɑz ʃʊɹ ði oʊɡiɝ kəd nɑt kip ɪt fəɹ lɔŋ, bʌt lɔɪəlz fit dɪd nɑt flæɡ. ɹænd dɪsaɪɾɪd ðəɾ ɪz boʊst ʌv wʌns aʊtʃɹʌnɪŋ ə hɔɹs maɪt ɹɪli bi tʃɹu. naʊ ən əɡɛn lɔɪəl lʊk bɪhaɪn əm əz i ɹæn, bʌt ðə ʃaʊts ə dɑɹkfɹɛnz ən haʊlz ə tʃɹɑləks feɪɾəd wɪð dɪstəns.

The pace Loial set was as fast as a horse could trot. Rand was sure the Ogier could not keep it for long, but Loial's feet did not flag. Rand decided that his boast of once outrunning a horse might really be true. Now and again Loial looked behind them as he ran, but the shouts of Darkfriends and howls of Trollocs faded with distance.

ivən wən ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪɡæn tə sloʊp ʌpwɝdz mɔɹ ʃɑɹpli, lɔɪəlz peɪs bɛɹli sloʊd, ən i tʃɹɑɾəd ɪndə ðɛɹ kæmpsaɪɾ ɑn ðə maʊntənsaɪd wɪð oʊnli ə lɪɾəl hɑɹd bɹiðɪŋ.

Even when the ground began to slope upwards more sharply, Loial's pace barely slowed, and he trotted into their campsite on the mountainside with only a little hard breathing.

"ju hæv ɪt." səlinz vɔɪs wɑz ɪɡzʌltən əz əɹ ɡeɪz ɹɛstəɾ ɑn ði ɔɹnətli wɝk tʃɛst ɑn lɔɪəlz sæɾəl. ʃi wɑz wɛɹɪŋ əɹ oʊn dʒɹɛs əɡɛn; ɪt lʊkt əz waɪɾ əz nu snoʊ tə ɹænd. "aɪ nu jə wəd meɪk ðə ɹaɪt tʃɔɪs. meɪ aɪ . . . hæv ə lʊk əɾ ɪt?"

"You have it." Selene's voice was exultant as her gaze rested on the ornately worked chest on Loial's saddle. She was wearing her own dress again; it looked as white as new snow to Rand. "I knew you would make the right choice. May I . . . have a look at it?"

"dɪɾ ɛni ʌv əm fɑloʊ, maɪ lɔɹd?" hʊɹɪn æskt æŋkʃəsli. hi stɛɹɾ ət ðə tʃɛst wɪð ɑ, bʌɾ ɪz aɪz slɪɾ ɔf ɪndə ðə naɪt, daʊn ðə maʊntən. "ɪf ðeɪ fɑloʊd, wɪl əv tə muv kwɪk."

"Did any of them follow, my Lord?" Hurin asked anxiously. He stared at the chest with awe, but his eyes slid off into the night, down the mountain. "If they followed, we'll have to move quick."

"aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk ðeɪ dɪd. ɡoʊ tə ði aʊtkɹɑp ən si ɪf jə kən si ɛniθɪŋ." ɹænd klaɪm daʊn fɹəm ɪz sæɾəl əz hʊɹɪn hɝiɾ ʌp ðə maʊntən. "səlin, aɪ doʊnt noʊ haʊ tə oʊpən ðə tʃɛst. lɔɪəl, də ju?" ði oʊɡiɝ ʃʊk ɪz hɛd.

"I do not think they did. Go to the outcrop and see if you can see anything." Rand climbed down from his saddle as Hurin hurried up the mountain. "Selene, I don't know how to open the chest. Loial, do you?" The Ogier shook his head.

"lɛt mi tʃɹaɪ. . . ." ivən fəɹ ə wʊmən ə səlinz haɪt, lɔɪəlz sæɾəl wɑz haɪ əbʌv ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ʃi ɹitʃt ʌp tə tʌtʃ ðə faɪnli ɹɔt pæɾɝnz ɑn ðə tʃɛst, ɹæn əɹ hænz əkɹɔs ðɛm, pɹɛst. ðəɹ wɑz ə klɪk, ən ʃi pʊʃt ðə lɪɾ ʌp, lɛɾ ɪt fɔl oʊpən.

"Let me try. . . ." Even for a woman of Selene's height, Loial's saddle was high above the ground. She reached up to touch the finely wrought patterns on the chest, ran her hands across them, pressed. There was a click, and she pushed the lid up, let it fall open.

əz ʃi stʃɹɛtʃt ɑn tɪptoʊ tə pʊɾ ə hæn ɪnsaɪd, ɹænd ɹitʃt oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ ən lɪftəɾ aʊt ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ. hi hæd sin ɪt wʌns bɪfɔɹ, bʌt nɛvɝ tʌtʃt ɪt. ðoʊ bjuɾəfli meɪd, ɪt dɪd nɑt lʊk ə θɪŋ ʌv ɡɹeɪɾ eɪdʒ, əɹ paʊɝ. ə kɝld ɡoʊldən hɔɹn, ɡlimɪŋ ɪn ðə feɪn laɪt, wɪð ɪnleɪd sɪlvɝ skɹɪp floʊɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə maʊθ ə ðə bɛl. hi tʌtʃt ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ lɛɾɝz wɪð ə fɪŋɡɝ. ðeɪ sim tə kætʃ ðə mun.

As she stretched on tiptoe to put a hand inside, Rand reached over her shoulder and lifted out the Horn of Valere. He had seen it once before, but never touched it. Though beautifully made, it did not look a thing of great age, or power. A curled golden horn, gleaming in the faint light, with inlaid silver script flowing around the mouth of the bell. He touched the strange letters with a finger. They seemed to catch the moon.

"tiə mi ɑveɪən mɔɹaɪɾɪn ɪeɪn veɪɾɪn," səlin sɛd. " 'ðə ɡɹeɪv ɪz noʊ bɑɹ tə maɪ kɔl.' jəl bi ɡɹeɪɾɝ ðən ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ ɛvɝ wɑz."

"Tia mi aven Moridin isainde vadin," Selene said. " 'The grave is no bar to my call.' You will be greater than Artur Hawkwing ever was."

"aɪ æm teɪkɪŋ ɪt tə ʃaɪnɝ, tə lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ." ɪt ʃəd ɡoʊ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn, hi θɔt, bʌɾ aɪm dʌn wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ. lɛɾ eɪɡəlmɝ əɹ ɪŋtʃɹ teɪk ɪt tə ðɛm. hi sɛt ðə hɔɹn bæk ɪn ðə tʃɛst; ɪt kæs bæk ðə munlaɪt, pʊl ði aɪ.

"I am taking it to Shienar, to Lord Agelmar." It should go to Tar Valon, he thought, but I'm done with Aes Sedai. Let Agelmar or Ingtar take it to them. He set the Horn back in the chest; it cast back the moonlight, pulled the eye.

"ðæɾ ɪz mædnəs," səlin sɛd.

"That is madness," Selene said.

ɹænd flɪntʃt ət ðə wɝd. "mæɾ əɹ nɑt, ɪts wʌɾ aɪm duɪŋ. aɪ toʊl ju, səlin, aɪ wɑnt noʊ pɑɹɾ ʌv ɡɹeɪtnəs. bæk ðɛɹ, aɪ θɔɾ aɪ dɪd. fəɹ ə waɪl, aɪ θɔɾ aɪ wɑntəd θɪŋz. . . ." laɪt, ʃiz soʊ bjuɾəfəl. ɛɡwin. səlin. aɪm nɑt wɝði ʌv iðɝ ə ðɛm. "sʌmθɪŋ sim tə teɪk hoʊld ə mi." seɪɾɪn keɪm fəɹ mi, bʌɾ aɪ fɔɾ ɪɾ ɔf wɪð ə sɔɹd. əɹ ɪz ðət mæd, tu? hi bɹið dipli. "ʃaɪnɝ ɪz wɛɹ ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ bɪlɔŋz. əɹ ɪf nɑt ðɛɹ, lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ wɪl noʊ wʌt tə də wɪð ɪt."

Rand flinched at the word. "Mad or not, it is what I'm doing. I told you, Selene, I want no part of greatness. Back there, I thought I did. For a while, I thought I wanted things. . . ." Light, she's so beautiful. Egwene. Selene. I'm not worthy of either of them. "Something seemed to take hold of me." Saidin came for me, but I fought it off with a sword. Or is that mad, too? He breathed deeply. "Shienar is where the Horn of Valere belongs. Or if not there, Lord Agelmar will know what to do with it."

hʊɹɪn əpɪɹd fɹəm ʌp ðə maʊntən. "ðə faɪɝz ðəɹ əɡɛn, lɔɹd ɹænd, ən bɪɡɝ ðən ɛvɝ. ən aɪ θɔɾ aɪ hɝd ʃaʊɾɪŋ. ɪt wɑz ɔl daʊn ɪn ðə hɪlz. aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðeɪv kʌm əpɑn ðə maʊntən, jɛt."

Hurin appeared from up the mountain. "The fire's there again, Lord Rand, and bigger than ever. And I thought I heard shouting. It was all down in the hills. I don't think they've come upon the mountain, yet."

"ju mɪsəndɝstæn mi, ɹænd," səlin sɛd. "ju kænɑt ɡoʊ bæk, naʊ. jə ɑɹ kəmɪɾəd. ðoʊz fɹɛnz ə ðə dɑɹk wɪl nɑt sɪmpli ɡoʊ əweɪ kəz juv teɪkən ðə hɔɹn fɹəm ðɛm. fɑɹ fɹəm ɪt. ənlɛs jə noʊ səm weɪ tə kɪl əm ɔl, ðəl bi hʌntɪŋ jə naʊ əz jə hʌntəɾ əm bɪfɔɹ."

"You misunderstand me, Rand," Selene said. "You cannot go back, now. You are committed. Those Friends of the Dark will not simply go away because you've taken the Horn from them. Far from it. Unless you know some way to kill them all, they will be hunting you now as you hunted them before."
