"noʊ!" lɔɪəl ən hʊɹɪn lʊk sɝpɹaɪzd ət ɹændz viəməns. hi sɔfən ɪz toʊn. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɛni weɪ tə kɪl əm ɔl. ðeɪ kən lɪv fɝɛvɝ fəɹ ɔl ə mi."

"No!" Loial and Hurin looked surprised at Rand's vehemence. He softened his tone. "I don't know any way to kill them all. They can live forever for all of me."

səlinz lɔŋ hɛɹ ʃɪftəɾ ɪn weɪvz əz ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "ðɛn jə kænɑt ɡoʊ bæk, oʊnli ɔnwɝd. jə kən ɹitʃ ðə seɪfti ʌv kɛɹhinz wɔlz lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ jə kəd ɹɪtɝn tə ʃaɪnɝ. dʌz ðə θɔɾ ʌv ə fju mɔɹ deɪz ɪn maɪ kʌmpəni sim soʊ oʊnɝəs?"

Selene's long hair shifted in waves as she shook her head. "Then you cannot go back, only onward. You can reach the safety of Cairhien's walls long before you could return to Shienar. Does the thought of a few more days in my company seem so onerous?"

ɹænd stɛɹɾ ət ðə tʃɛst. səlinz kʌmpəni wɑz fɑɹ fɹəm bɝɾənsəm, bʌt nɪɹ əɹ i kəd nɑt hɛlp θɪŋkɪŋ θɪŋz i ʃəd nɑt. stɪl, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹaɪd bæk nɔɹθ mɛn ɹɪskɪŋ feɪn ən ɪz fɑloʊɝz. ʃi wɑz ɹaɪɾ ɪn ðæt. feɪn wəd nɛvɝ ɡɪv ʌp. ɪŋtʃɹ wəd nɑt ɡɪv ʌp, iðɝ. ɪf ɪŋtʃɹ keɪm ɑn saʊθwɝd, ən ɹænd nu ʌv noʊ ɹizən fəɹ ɪm tə tɝn əsaɪd, hi wəɾ ɝaɪv ət kɛɹhin, sun əɹ leɪt.

Rand stared at the chest. Selene's company was far from burdensome, but near her he could not help thinking things he should not. Still, trying to ride back north meant risking Fain and his followers. She was right in that. Fain would never give up. Ingtar would not give up, either. If Ingtar came on southward, and Rand knew of no reason for him to turn aside, he would arrive at Cairhien, soon or late.

"kɛɹhin," hi əɡɹid. "ju wɪl əv tə ʃoʊ mi wɛɹ jə laɪv, səlin. aɪv nɛvɝ bɪn tə kɛɹhin." hi ɹitʃt tə kloʊz ðə tʃɛst.

"Cairhien," he agreed. "You will have to show me where you live, Selene. I've never been to Cairhien." He reached to close the chest.

"ju tʊk sʌmθɪŋ ɛls fɹəm ðə fɹɛnz ə ðə dɑɹk?" səlin sɛd. "ju spoʊk ɝliɝ ʌv ə dæɡɝ."

"You took something else from the Friends of the Dark?" Selene said. "You spoke earlier of a dagger."

haʊ kəɾ aɪ fɝɡɛt? hi lɛf ðə tʃɛst əz ɪt wɑz ən pʊl ðə dæɡɝ fɹəm ɪz bɛlt. ðə bɛɹ bleɪd kɝv laɪk ə hɔɹn, ən ðə kwɪlənz wɝ ɡoʊldən sɝpəns. sɛɾ ɪn ðə hɪlt, ə ɹubi əz bɪɡ əz ɪz θʌmneɪl wɪŋk laɪk ən ivəl aɪ ɪn ðə munlaɪt. ɔɹneɪɾ əz ɪt wɑz, teɪntɪɾ əz i nu ɪt wɑz, ɪt fɛl noʊ dɪfɹən fɹəm ɛni ʌðɝ naɪf.

How could I forget? He left the chest as it was and pulled the dagger from his belt. The bare blade curved like a horn, and the quillons were golden serpents. Set in the hilt, a ruby as big as his thumbnail winked like an evil eye in the moonlight. Ornate as it was, tainted as he knew it was, it felt no different from any other knife.

"bi kɛɹfəl," səlin sɛd. "du nɑt kʌt jɝsɛlf."

"Be careful," Selene said. "Do not cut yourself."

ɹænd fɛlt ə ʃɪvɝ ɪnsaɪd. ɪf sɪmpli kæɹiɪŋ ɪt wɑz deɪnʒɝəs, hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə noʊ wʌɾ ə kʌt fɹəm ɪt wəd du. "ðɪs ɪz fɹəm ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ," hi toʊl ði ʌðɝz. "ɪt wɪl twɪs huɛvɝ kæɹiz ɪt fəɹ lɔŋ, teɪn əm tə ðə boʊn ðə weɪ ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ ɪz teɪntɪd. wɪθaʊɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ hilɪŋ, ðət teɪnt wɪl kɪl, ɪvɛntʃəwəli."

Rand felt a shiver inside. If simply carrying it was dangerous, he did not want to know what a cut from it would do. "This is from Shadar Logoth," he told the others. "It will twist whoever carries it for long, taint them to the bone the way Shadar Logoth is tainted. Without Aes Sedai Healing, that taint will kill, eventually."

"soʊ ðəɾ ɪz wʌɾ eɪlz mæt," lɔɪəl sɛd sɔfli. "aɪ nɛvɝ səspɛktəd." hʊɹɪn stɛɹɾ ət ðə dæɡɝ ɪn ɹændz hæn ən waɪpt ɪz oʊn hænz ɑn ðə fɹʌn ə hɪz koʊt. ðə snɪfɝ dɪd nɑt lʊk hæpi.

"So that is what ails Mat," Loial said softly. "I never suspected." Hurin stared at the dagger in Rand's hand and wiped his own hands on the front of his coat. The sniffer did not look happy.

"nʌn ʌv əs mʌs hændəl ɪɾ ɛni mɔɹ ðən ɪz nɛsəsɛɹi," ɹænd wɛn ɑn. "aɪ wɪl faɪn səm weɪ tə kæɹi ɪt - "

"None of us must handle it any more than is necessary," Rand went on. "I will find some way to carry it - "

"ɪɾ ɪz deɪnʒɝəs." səlin fɹaʊn ət ðə bleɪɾ əz ɪf ðə sneɪks wɝ ɹil, ən pɔɪzənəs. "θɹoʊ ɪɾ əweɪ. liv ɪt, əɹ bɛɹi ɪɾ ɪf jə wɪʃ tə kip ɪt fɹəm ʌðɝ hænz, bʌt bi ɹɪɾ ʌv ɪt."

"It is dangerous." Selene frowned at the blade as if the snakes were real, and poisonous. "Throw it away. Leave it, or bury it if you wish to keep it from other hands, but be rid of it."

"mæt nidz ɪt," ɹænd sɛd fɝmli.

"Mat needs it," Rand said firmly.

"ɪɾ ɪz tu deɪnʒɝəs. jə sɛd soʊ jɝsɛlf."

"It is too dangerous. You said so yourself."

"hi nidz ɪt. ði æm . . . ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛɾ i wəd daɪ wɪθaʊɾ ɪt tə juz ɪn hilɪŋ hɪm." ðeɪ stɪl əv ə stʃɹɪŋ ɑn hɪm, bʌt ðɪs bleɪd wɪl kʌɾ ɪt. əntɪl aɪm ɹɪɾ ʌv ɪt, ən ðə hɔɹn, ðeɪv ə stʃɹɪŋ ɑn mi, bʌɾ əl nɑt dæns haʊɛvɝ mʌtʃ ðeɪ pʊl.

"He needs it. The Am . . . the Aes Sedai said he would die without it to use in Healing him." They still have a string on him, but this blade will cut it. Until I'm rid of it, and the Horn, they have a string on me, but I'll not dance however much they pull.

hi sɛt ðə dæɡɝ ɪn ðə tʃɛst, ɪnsaɪd ðə kɝl ə ðə hɔɹn - ðəɹ wɑz dʒʌst ɹum fəɹ ɪt - ən pʊl ðə lɪd daʊn. ɪt lɑkt wɪð ə ʃɑɹp snæp. "ðæt ʃəd ʃild əs fɹəm ɪt." hi hoʊpt ɪt wʊd. læn sɛd ðə taɪm tə saʊn moʊst ʃʊɹ wɑz wən jə wɝ list sɝɾən.

He set the dagger in the chest, inside the curl of the Horn - there was just room for it - and pulled the lid down. It locked with a sharp snap. "That should shield us from it." He hoped it would. Lan said the time to sound most sure was when you were least certain.

"ðə tʃɛst wɪl ʃʊɹli ʃild ʌs," səlin sɛɾ ɪn ə taɪt vɔɪs. "ænd naʊ aɪ min tə fɪnɪʃ wʌɾ ɪz lɛft ə maɪ naɪts slip."

"The chest will surely shield us," Selene said in a tight voice. "And now I mean to finish what is left of my night's sleep."

ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "wi ɑɹ tu kloʊs. feɪn simz eɪbəl tə faɪn mi, səmtaɪmz."

Rand shook his head. "We are too close. Fain seems able to find me, sometimes."

"sik ðə wʌnnəs ɪf jə ɑɹ əfɹeɪd," səlin sɛd.

"Seek the Oneness if you are afraid," Selene said.

"aɪ wɑnə bi əz fɑɹ fɹəm ðoʊz dɑɹkfɹɛnz kʌm mɔɹnɪŋ əz wi kən bi. əl sæɾəl jəɹ mɛɹ."

"I want to be as far from those Darkfriends come morning as we can be. I will saddle your mare."

"stʌbɝn!" ʃi saʊndəɾ æŋɡɹi, ən wən i lʊkt ət hɝ, hɝ maʊθ kɝvd ɪn ə smaɪl ðət nɛvɝ keɪm kloʊs tə hɝ dɑɹk aɪz. "ə stʌbɝn mæn ɪz bɛst, wʌns. . . ." hɝ vɔɪs tʃɹeɪld ɔf, ən ðət wɝid hɪm. wɪmən ɔfən sim tə liv θɪŋz ənsɛd, ən ɪn ɪz lɪməɾəd ɪkspɪɹiəns ɪt wɑz wʌt ðeɪ dɪd nɑt seɪ ðət pɹuv ðə moʊs tʃɹʌbəl. ʃi wɑtʃt ɪn saɪləns əz i slʌŋ əɹ sæɾəl ɑntu ðə waɪt mɛɹz bæk ən bɛn tə fæʃən ðə ɡɝθs.

"Stubborn!" She sounded angry, and when he looked at her, her mouth curved in a smile that never came close to her dark eyes. "A stubborn man is best, once. . . ." Her voice trailed off, and that worried him. Women often seemed to leave things unsaid, and in his limited experience it was what they did not say that proved the most trouble. She watched in silence as he slung her saddle onto the white mare's back and bent to fashion the girths.

"ɡæðɝ əm ɔl ɪn!" feɪn snɑɹəld. ðə ɡoʊt-snaʊɾəd tʃɹɑlɑk bækt əweɪ fɹəm hɪm. ðə faɪɝ, paɪl haɪ wɪð wʊd naʊ, lɪt ðə hɪltɑp wɪð flɪkɝɪŋ ʃædoʊz. hɪz hjumən fɑloʊɝz hʌɾəld nɪɹ ðə bleɪz, fɪɹfəl tə bi aʊɾ ɪn ðə dɑɹk wɪð ðə ɹɛst ə ðə tʃɹɑləks. "ɡæðɝ ðɛm, ɛvɹi wʌn ðət stɪl laɪvz, ən ɪf ɛni θɪŋk tə ɹʌn, lɛɾ əm noʊ ðəl ɡɛt wʌt ðət wʌn ɡɑt." hi dʒɛstʃɝd tə ðə fɝs tʃɹɑlɑk ðət hæd bɹɔɾ ɪm wɝɾ ælθɹ wɑz nɑt tə bi faʊnd. ɪt stɪl snæpt ət ɡɹaʊn mʌɾid wɪð ɪts oʊn blʌd, hʊvz skɹeɪpɪŋ tʃɹɛntʃɪz əz ðeɪ dʒɝkt. "ɡoʊ," feɪn wɪspɝd, ən ðə ɡoʊt-snaʊɾəd tʃɹɑlɑk ɹæn ɪndə ðə naɪt.

"Gather them all in!" Fain snarled. The goat-snouted Trolloc backed away from him. The fire, piled high with wood now, lit the hilltop with flickering shadows. His human followers huddled near the blaze, fearful to be out in the dark with the rest of the Trollocs. "Gather them, every one that still lives, and if any think to run, let them know they'll get what that one got." He gestured to the first Trolloc that had brought him word al'Thor was not to be found. It still snapped at ground muddied with its own blood, hooves scraping trenches as they jerked. "Go," Fain whispered, and the goat-snouted Trolloc ran into the night.

feɪn ɡlæns kəntɛmptʃwəsli ət ði ʌðɝ hjumənz - ðəl əv ðɛɹ juzɪz stɪl - ðən tɝn tə stɛɹ ɪndə ðə naɪt, təwɔɹd kɪnsleɪɝz dæɡɝ. ælθɹ wɑz ʌp ðɛɹ, sʌmwɛɹ, ɪn ðə maʊntənz. wɪð ðə hɔɹn. hɪz tiθ ɡɹeɪɾɪd ɑɾəbli ət ðə θɔt. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ wɛɹ, ɪɡzækli, bʌt sʌmθɪŋ pʊld ɪm təwɔɹd ðə maʊntənz. təwɔɹɾ ælθɹ. ðət mʌtʃ ə ðə dɑɹk wʌnz . . . ɡɪft . . . ɹɪmeɪn tə hɪm. hi hæd hɑɹdli θɔɾ ʌv ɪt, hæd tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə θɪŋk ʌv ɪt, əntɪl sʌɾənli, æftɝ ðə hɔɹn wɑz ɡɔn - ɡɔn! - ælθɹ wɑz ðɛɹ, dʒɹɔɪŋ ɪm əz mit dʒɹɔz ə stɑɹvɪŋ dɔɡ.

Fain glanced contemptuously at the other humans - They'll have their uses still - then turned to stare into the night, toward Kinslayer's Dagger. Al'Thor was up there, somewhere, in the mountains. With the Horn. His teeth grated audibly at the thought. He did not know where, exactly, but something pulled him toward the mountains. Toward al'Thor. That much of the Dark One's . . . gift . . . remained to him. He had hardly thought of it, had tried not to think of it, until suddenly, after the Horn was gone - Gone! - al'Thor was there, drawing him as meat draws a starving dog.

"aɪ æm ə dɔɡ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ. ə dɔɡ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ!" hi hɝd ði ʌðɝz ʃɪftɪŋ ənizəli ɝaʊn ðə faɪɝ, bʌɾ i ɪɡnɔɹd ðɛm. "ju wɪl peɪ fəɹ wʌt wɑz dʌn tə mi, ælθɹ! ðə wɝld wɪl peɪ!" hi kækəld ət ðə naɪt wɪð mæd læftɝ. "ðə wɝld wɪl peɪ!"

"I am a dog no longer. A dog no longer!" He heard the others shifting uneasily around the fire, but he ignored them. "You will pay for what was done to me, al'Thor! The world will pay!" He cackled at the night with mad laughter. "The world will pay!"


tʃæptɝ twɛnti


CHAPTER 20

seɪɾɪn


Saidin

ɹænd kɛpt əm muvɪŋ θɹu ðə naɪt, əlaʊɪŋ oʊnli ə bɹif stɑp ət dɔn, tə ɹɛs ðə hɔɹsəz. ən tə əlaʊ lɔɪəl ɹɛst. wɪð ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ ɪn ɪts ɡoʊld-ænd-sɪlvɝ tʃɛst ɑkjəpaɪɪŋ ɪz sæɾəl, ði oʊɡiɝ wɔkt əɹ tʃɹɑɾəd əhɛɾ ə hɪz bɪɡ hɔɹs, nɛvɝ kəmpleɪnɪŋ, nɛvɝ sloʊɪŋ ðɛm. sʌmtaɪm dʊɹɪŋ ðə naɪt ðeɪ hæd kɹɔs ðə bɔɹɾɝ ə kɛɹhin.

Rand kept them moving through the night, allowing only a brief stop at dawn, to rest the horses. And to allow Loial rest. With the Horn of Valere in its gold-and-silver chest occupying his saddle, the Ogier walked or trotted ahead of his big horse, never complaining, never slowing them. Sometime during the night they had crossed the border of Cairhien.

"aɪ wɑnə si ɪɾ əɡɛn," səlin sɛɾ əz ðeɪ hɔltəd. ʃi dɪsmaʊntɪɾ ən stʃɹoʊd tə lɔɪəlz hɔɹs. ðɛɹ ʃædoʊz, lɔŋ ən θɪn, pɔɪntəd wɛs fɹəm ðə sʌn dʒʌs pikɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə hɝaɪzən. "bɹɪŋ ɪt daʊn fəɹ mi, ælɑntɪn." lɔɪəl bɪɡæn tə əndu ðə stʃɹæps. "ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ."

"I want to see it again," Selene said as they halted. She dismounted and strode to Loial's horse. Their shadows, long and thin, pointed west from the sun just peeking over the horizon. "Bring it down for me, alantin." Loial began to undo the straps. "The Horn of Valere."

"noʊ," ɹænd sɛd, klaɪmɪŋ daʊn fɹəm ɹɛdz bæk. "lɔɪəl, noʊ." ði oʊɡiɝ lʊk fɹəm ɹænd tə səlin, hɪz ɪɹz twɪtʃɪŋ daʊtfəli, bʌɾ i tʊk ɪz hænz əweɪ.

"No," Rand said, climbing down from Red's back. "Loial, no." The Ogier looked from Rand to Selene, his ears twitching doubtfully, but he took his hands away.

"aɪ wɑnə si ðə hɔɹn," səlin dɪmændəd. ɹænd wɑz ʃʊɹ ʃi wɑz noʊ oʊldɝ ðən hi, bʌɾ ət ðət moʊmənt ʃi sʌɾənli simd əz oʊld ən əz koʊld əz ðə maʊntənz, ən mɔɹ ɹiɡəl ðən kwin mɔɹɡeɪs əɾ əɹ hɔɾiəst.

"I want to see the Horn," Selene demanded. Rand was sure she was no older than he, but at that moment she suddenly seemed as old and as cold as the mountains, and more regal than Queen Morgase at her haughtiest.

"aɪ θɪŋk wi ʃəd kip ðə dæɡɝ ʃildɪd," ɹænd sɛd. "fɔɹ ɔl aɪ noʊ, lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪt meɪ bi əz bæɾ əz tʌtʃɪŋ ɪt. lɛɾ ɪt steɪ wɛɹ ɪts əntɪl aɪ kən pʊɾ ɪɾ ɪn mæts hænz. hi - hi kən teɪk ɪt tə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ." ən wʌt pɹaɪs wɪl ðeɪ dɪmæn fəɹ ðət hilɪŋ? bʌɾ i hæzən ɛni tʃɔɪs. hi fɛlt ə lɪɾəl ɡɪlti oʊvɝ filɪŋ ɹɪlif ðət hi, ət list, wɑz θɹu wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ. aɪm dʌn wɪð ðɛm. wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ.

"I think we should keep the dagger shielded," Rand said. "For all I know, looking at it may be as bad as touching it. Let it stay where it is until I can put it in Mat's hands. He - he can take it to the Aes Sedai." And what price will they demand for that Healing? But he hasn't any choice. He felt a little guilty over feeling relief that he, at least, was through with Aes Sedai. I am done with them. One way or another.

"ðə dæɡɝ! ɔl jə sim tə kɛɹ əbaʊɾ ɪz ðət dæɡɝ. aɪ toʊl jə tə bi ɹɪɾ ʌv ɪt. ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ, ɹænd."

"The dagger! All you seem to care about is that dagger. I told you to be rid of it. The Horn of Valere, Rand."

"noʊ."

"No."

ʃi keɪm tə hɪm, ə sweɪ ɪn əɹ wɔk ðət meɪɾ ɪm fil əz ɪf i hæd sʌmθɪŋ kɑɾ ɪn ɪz θɹoʊt. "ɔl aɪ wɑn ɪz tə si ɪɾ ɪn ðə laɪɾ ə deɪ. aɪ woʊn ivən tʌtʃ ɪt. jə hoʊld ɪt. ɪt wəd bi sʌmθɪŋ fəɹ mi tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ, jə hoʊldɪŋ ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ ɪn jəɹ hænz." ʃi tʊk ɪz hænz əz ʃi sɛɾ ɪt; hɝ tʌtʃ meɪɾ ɪz skɪn tɪŋɡəl ən ɪz maʊθ ɡoʊ dʒɹaɪ.

She came to him, a sway in her walk that made him feel as if he had something caught in his throat. "All I want is to see it in the light of day. I won't even touch it. You hold it. It would be something for me to remember, you holding the Horn of Valere in your hands." She took his hands as she said it; her touch made his skin tingle and his mouth go dry.

sʌmθɪŋ tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ - wən ʃi hæd ɡɔn. . . . hi kəd kloʊz ðə dæɡɝ ʌp əɡɛn əz sun əz ðə hɔɹn wɑz aʊɾ ə ðə tʃɛst. ɪt wəd bi sʌmθɪŋ tə hoʊl ðə hɔɹn ɪn ɪz hænz wɛɹ i kəd si ɪɾ ɪn ðə laɪt.

Something to remember - when she had gone. . . . He could close the dagger up again as soon as the Horn was out of the chest. It would be something to hold the Horn in his hands where he could see it in the light.

hi wɪʃt i nu mɔɹ ə ðə pɹɑfəsiz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən. ðə wʌn taɪm i hɝɾ ə mɝtʃəns ɡɑɹd tɛlɪŋ ə pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt, bæk ɪn ɛmənz fild, nɪneɪiv hæd bɹoʊkən ə bɹum əkɹɔs ðə mænz ʃoʊldɝz. nʌn ə ðə lɪɾəl i hæd hɝd mɛnʃən ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ.

He wished he knew more of the Prophecies of the Dragon. The one time he heard a merchant's guard telling a part of it, back in Emond's Field, Nynaeve had broken a broom across the man's shoulders. None of the little he had heard mentioned the Horn of Valere.

ɛɛs sədaɪ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk mi də wʌt ðeɪ wɑnt. səlin wɑz stɪl ɡeɪzɪŋ ɪntɛnli ɪndə hɪz aɪz, hɝ feɪs soʊ jʌŋ ən bjuɾəfəl ðəɾ i wɑntəd tə kɪs əɹ dɪspaɪt wʌɾ i wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ. hi hæd nɛvɝ sin ən ɛɛs sədaɪ æk ðə weɪ ʃi dɪd, ən ʃi lʊk jʌŋ, nɑɾ eɪdʒləs. ə ɡɝl maɪ eɪdʒ kʊdn bi ɛɛs sədaɪ. bʌt. . . .

Aes Sedai trying to make me do what they want. Selene was still gazing intently into his eyes, her face so young and beautiful that he wanted to kiss her despite what he was thinking. He had never seen an Aes Sedai act the way she did, and she looked young, not ageless. A girl my age couldn't be Aes Sedai. But. . . .

"səlin," hi sɛd sɔfli, "ɑɹ jə ən ɛɛs sədaɪ?"

"Selene," he said softly, "are you an Aes Sedai?"

"ɛɛs sədaɪ," ʃi ɔlmoʊst spæt, flɪŋɪŋ ɪz hænz əweɪ. "ɛɛs sədaɪ! ɔlweɪz jə hɝl ðəɾ ət mi!" ʃi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ ən smuðd əɹ dʒɹɛs, əz ɪf ɡæðɝɪŋ hɝsɛlf. "aɪ æm wʌɾ ən u aɪ æm. ən aɪm noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ!" ən ʃi ɹæp hɝsɛlf ɪn ə saɪlən koʊlnəs ðət meɪɾ ivən ðə mɔɹnɪŋ sʌn sim tʃɪl.

"Aes Sedai," she almost spat, flinging his hands away. "Aes Sedai! Always you hurl that at me!" She took a deep breath and smoothed her dress, as if gathering herself. "I am what and who I am. And I am no Aes Sedai!" And she wrapped herself in a silent coldness that made even the morning sun seem chill.

lɔɪəl ən hʊɹɪn bɔɹ ɪɾ ɔl wɪð əz ɡʊɾ ə ɡɹeɪs əz ðeɪ kəd mænədʒ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk kɑnvɝseɪʃən ən haɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ ɪmbɛɹəsmənt wən ʃi fɹoʊz əm wɪð ə lʊk. ðeɪ ɹoʊɾ ɑn.

Loial and Hurin bore it all with as good a grace as they could manage, trying to make conversation and hiding their embarrassment when she froze them with a look. They rode on.

baɪ ðə taɪm ðeɪ meɪd kæmp ðət naɪt bɪsaɪɾ ə maʊntən stʃɹim ðət pɹəvaɪɾəd fɪʃ fəɹ ðɛɹ sʌpɝ, səlin sim tə hæv ɹiɡeɪn səm ə hɝ tɛmpɝ, tʃæɾɪŋ wɪð ði oʊɡiɝ əbaʊt bʊks, spikɪŋ kaɪnli tə hʊɹɪn.

By the time they made camp that night beside a mountain stream that provided fish for their supper, Selene seemed to have regained some of her temper, chatting with the Ogier about books, speaking kindly to Hurin.

ʃi bɛɹli spoʊk tə ɹænd, ðoʊ, ənlɛs i spoʊk fɝst, iðɝ ðəɾ ivnɪŋ əɹ ðə fɑloʊɪŋ deɪ əz ðeɪ ɹoʊd θɹu maʊntənz ðət ɹɪɹɾ ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ə ðɛm laɪk hjudʒ, dʒæɡd ɡɹeɪ wɔlz, ɛvɝ klaɪmɪŋ. bʌt wɛnɛvɝ i lʊkt ət hɝ, ʃi wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ ɪm ən smaɪlɪŋ. səmtaɪmz ɪt wɑz ðə sɔɹɾ ə smaɪl ðət meɪɾ ɪm smaɪl bæk, səmtaɪmz ðə sɔɹt ðət meɪɾ ɪm klɪɹ ɪz θɹoʊɾ ən blʌʃ əɾ ɪz oʊn θɔts, ən səmtaɪmz ðə mɪstɪɹiəs, noʊɪŋ smaɪl ðəɾ ɛɡwin səmtaɪmz wɔɹ. ɪt wɑz ə kaɪndə smaɪl ðəɾ ɔlweɪz pʊɾ ɪz bæk ʌp - bʌɾ ət list ɪt wɑz ə smaɪl.

She barely spoke to Rand, though, unless he spoke first, either that evening or the following day as they rode through mountains that reared on either side of them like huge, jagged gray walls, ever climbing. But whenever he looked at her, she was watching him and smiling. Sometimes it was the sort of smile that made him smile back, sometimes the sort that made him clear his throat and blush at his own thoughts, and sometimes the mysterious, knowing smile that Egwene sometimes wore. It was a kind of smile that always put his back up - but at least it was a smile.

ʃi kæn bi ɛɛs sədaɪ.

She can't be Aes Sedai.

ðə weɪ bɪɡæn tə sloʊp daʊnwɝdz, ən wɪð ðə pɹɑməs ə twaɪlaɪɾ ɪn ði ɛɹ, kɪnsleɪɝz dæɡɝ ət læst ɡeɪv weɪ tə hɪlz, ɹoʊlɪŋ ən ɹaʊnd, wɪð mɔɹ bɹʌʃ ðən tʃɹiz, mɔɹ θɪkəts ðən fɔɹəst. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɹoʊd, dʒʌst ə dɝt tʃɹæk, sətʃ əz maɪt bi juz baɪ ə fju kɑɹts naʊ ən əɡɛn. filz kɑɹv səm ə ðə hɪlz ɪndə tɛɹəsəz, filz fʊl ə kɹɑps bʌɾ ɛmpti ʌv pipəl ət ðɪs aʊɝ. nʌn ə ðə skæɾɝd fɑɹm bɪldɪŋz leɪ kloʊs ɪnʌf tə ðə pæθ ðeɪ ɹoʊd fəɹ ɹænd tə meɪk aʊt mɔɹ ðən ðət ðeɪ wɝ ɔl meɪɾ ə stoʊn.

The way began to slope downwards, and with the promise of twilight in the air, Kinslayer's Dagger at last gave way to hills, rolling and round, with more brush than trees, more thickets than forest. There was no road, just a dirt track, such as might be used by a few carts now and again. Fields carved some of the hills into terraces, fields full of crops but empty of people at this hour. None of the scattered farm buildings lay close enough to the path they rode for Rand to make out more than that they were all made of stone.

wən i sɔ ðə vɪlədʒ əhɛd, laɪts ɔlɹɛɾi twɪŋkəld ɪn ə fju wɪndoʊz əɡɛns ðə kʌmɪŋ ə naɪt.

When he saw the village ahead, lights already twinkled in a few windows against the coming of night.

"wil slip ɪn bɛdz tənaɪt," hi sɛd.

"We'll sleep in beds tonight," he said.

"ðæɾ əl ɛndʒɔɪ, lɔɹd ɹænd." hʊɹɪn læft. lɔɪəl nɑɾəd əɡɹimənt.

"That I will enjoy, Lord Rand." Hurin laughed. Loial nodded agreement.

"ə vɪlədʒ ɪn," səlin snɪft. "dɝɾi, noʊ daʊt, ən fʊl ʌv ənwɑʃt mɛn swɪlɪŋ eɪl. waɪ kænt wi slip ʌndɝ ðə stɑɹz əɡɛn? aɪ faɪn aɪ ɛndʒɔɪ slipɪŋ ʌndɝ ðə stɑɹz."

"A village inn," Selene sniffed. "Dirty, no doubt, and full of unwashed men swilling ale. Why can't we sleep under the stars again? I find I enjoy sleeping under the stars."

"ju wəd nɑɾ ɛndʒɔɪ ɪɾ ɪf feɪn kɑɾ ʌp wɪð əs waɪl wi slɛpt," ɹænd sɛd, "hɪm ən ðoʊz tʃɹɑləks. hiz kʌmɪŋ æftɝ mi, səlin. æftɝ ðə hɔɹn, tu, bʌɾ ɪts mi hi kən faɪnd. waɪ dʒju θɪŋk aɪv kɛp sətʃ ə kloʊs wɑtʃ ðiz pæs naɪts?"

"You would not enjoy it if Fain caught up with us while we slept," Rand said, "him and those Trollocs. He's coming after me, Selene. After the Horn, too, but it is me he can find. Why do you think I've kept such a close watch these past nights?"

"ɪf feɪn kætʃəz ʌs, jəl dil wɪð hɪm." hɝ vɔɪs wɑz kuli kɑnfəɾənt. "æn ðəɹ kəd bi dɑɹkfɹɛnz ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ, tu."

"If Fain catches us, you will deal with him." Her voice was coolly confident. "And there could be Darkfriends in the village, too."

"bʌɾ ivən ɪf ðeɪ nu hu wi ɑɹ, ðeɪ kæn də mʌtʃ wɪð ðə ɹɛst ə ðə vɪlɪdʒɝz ɝaʊnd. nɑɾ ənlɛs jə θɪŋk ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ ɪz ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd."

"But even if they knew who we are, they can't do much with the rest of the villagers around. Not unless you think everyone in the village is a Darkfriend."

"æn ɪf ðeɪ dɪskʌvɝ jə kæɹi ðə hɔɹn? wɛðɝ jə wɑnt ɡɹeɪtnəs əɹ nɑt, ivən fɑɹmɝz dʒɹim ʌv ɪt."

"And if they discover you carry the Horn? Whether you want greatness or not, even farmers dream of it."

"ʃi ɪz ɹaɪt, ɹænd," lɔɪəl sɛd. "aɪ fɪɹ ivən fɑɹmɝz maɪt wɑnə teɪk ɪt."

"She is right, Rand," Loial said. "I fear even farmers might want to take it."

"ənɹoʊl jəɹ blæŋkət, lɔɪəl, ən θɹoʊ ɪɾ oʊvɝ ðə tʃɛst. kip ɪt kʌvɝd." lɔɪəl kəmplaɪd, ən ɹænd nɑɾəd. ɪt wɑz ɑbviəs ðəɹ wɑz ə bɑks əɹ tʃɛs bɪniθ ði oʊɡiɝz stʃɹaɪp blæŋkət, bʌt nʌθɪŋ sədʒɛstəɾ ɪt wɑz mɔɹ ðən ə tʃɹævəl tʃɛst. "maɪ leɪɾiz tʃɛst ə kloʊðz," ɹænd sɛd wɪð ə ɡɹɪn ən ə baʊ.

"Unroll your blanket, Loial, and throw it over the chest. Keep it covered." Loial complied, and Rand nodded. It was obvious there was a box or chest beneath the Ogier's striped blanket, but nothing suggested it was more than a travel chest. "My Lady's chest of clothes," Rand said with a grin and a bow.

səlin mɛɾ ɪz sæli wɪð saɪləns ən ən ənɹiɾəbəl lʊk. æftɝ ə moʊmənt, ðeɪ stɑɹɾəd ɑn əɡɛn.

Selene met his sally with silence and an unreadable look. After a moment, they started on again.

ɔlmoʊst ɪmiɾiətli, ɔf tə ɹændz lɛft, ə ɡlɪɾɝ fɹəm ðə sɛɾɪŋ sʌn ɹəflɛktəd fɹəm sʌmθɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. sʌmθɪŋ lɑɹdʒ. sʌmθɪŋ vɛɹi lɑɹdʒ, baɪ ðə laɪɾ ɪt θɹu ʌp. kjʊɹiəs, hi tɝn ɪz hɔɹs ðət weɪ.

Almost immediately, off to Rand's left, a glitter from the setting sun reflected from something on the ground. Something large. Something very large, by the light it threw up. Curious, he turned his horse that way.

"maɪ lɔɹd?" hʊɹɪn sɛd. "ðə vɪlədʒ?"

"My Lord?" Hurin said. "The village?"

"aɪ dʒʌst wɑnə si ðɪs fɝst," ɹænd sɛd. ɪts bɹaɪɾɝ ðən sʌnlaɪɾ ɑn wɔɾɝ. wʌt kən ɪt bi?

"I just want to see this first," Rand said. It's brighter than sunlight on water. What can it be?

hɪz aɪz ɑn ðə ɹəflɛkʃən, hi wɑz sɝpɹaɪzd wən ɹɛd sʌɾənli stɑpt. ɑn ðə pɔɪn ə ɝdʒɪŋ ðə beɪ ɑn, hi ɹilaɪz ðət ðeɪ stʊɾ ɑn ði ɛdʒ ʌv ə kleɪ pɹɛsəpəs, əbʌv ə hjudʒ ɛkskəveɪʃən. moʊst ə ðə hɪl hæd bɪn dʌɡ əweɪ tə ə dɛpθ ʌv izəli ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz. sɝɾənli mɔɹ ðən wʌn hɪl hæd vænɪʃt, ən meɪbi səm fɑɹmɝz' filz, fəɹ ðə hoʊl wɑz ət lis tɛn taɪmz əz waɪɾ əz ɪt wɑz dip. ðə fɑɹ saɪɾ əpɪɹd tə hæv bɪn pæk hɑɹd tə ə ɹæmp. ðəɹ wɝ mɛn ɑn ðə bɑɾəm, ə dʌzən ə ðɛm, ɡɛɾɪŋ ə faɪɝ stɑɹɾəd; daʊn ðɛɹ, naɪt wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi dɪsɛndɪŋ. hɪɹ ən ðəɹ əmʌŋ əm ɑɹmɝ tɝn ðə laɪt, ən sɔɹdz swʌŋ ət ðɛɹ saɪdz. hi hɑɹdli ɡlænst ət ðɛm.

His eyes on the reflection, he was surprised when Red suddenly stopped. On the point of urging the bay on, he realized that they stood on the edge of a clay precipice, above a huge excavation. Most of the hill had been dug away to a depth of easily a hundred paces. Certainly more than one hill had vanished, and maybe some farmers' fields, for the hole was at least ten times as wide as it was deep. The far side appeared to have been packed hard to a ramp. There were men on the bottom, a dozen of them, getting a fire started; down there, night was already descending. Here and there among them armor turned the light, and swords swung at their sides. He hardly glanced at them.

aʊɾ ə ðə kleɪ ət ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə pɪt slæntəɾ ə dʒaɪɡæntɪk stoʊn hæn hoʊldɪŋ ə kɹɪstəl sfɪɹ, ən ɪt wɑz ðɪs ðət ʃoʊn wɪð ðə læst sʌnlaɪt. ɹænd ɡeɪpt ət ðə saɪz ʌv ɪt, ə smuð bɔl - hi wɑz ʃʊɹ nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə skɹætʃ mɑɹɾ ɪts sɝfəs - ət lis twɛnti peɪsɪz θɹu.

Out of the clay at the bottom of the pit slanted a gigantic stone hand holding a crystal sphere, and it was this that shone with the last sunlight. Rand gaped at the size of it, a smooth ball - he was sure not so much as a scratch marred its surface - at least twenty paces through.

səm dɪstəns əweɪ fɹəm ðə hænd, ə stoʊn feɪs ɪn pɹəpɔɹʃən hæd bɪn ənkʌvɝd. ə bɪɹɾəd mænz feɪs, ɪt θɹʌst aʊɾ ə ðə sɔɪl wɪð ðə dɪɡnəɾi ʌv væs jɪɹz; ðə bɹɔd fitʃɝz sim tə hoʊld wɪzdəm ən nɑlədʒ.

Some distance away from the hand, a stone face in proportion had been uncovered. A bearded man's face, it thrust out of the soil with the dignity of vast years; the broad features seemed to hold wisdom and knowledge.

ənsʌmənd, ðə vɔɪd fɔɹmd, hoʊl ən kəmpliɾ ɪn ən ɪnstənt, seɪɾɪn ɡloʊɪŋ, bɛkənɪŋ. soʊ ɪntɛnt wɑz i ɑn ðə feɪs ən ðə hæn ðəɾ i dɪd nɑɾ ivən ɹilaɪz wʌt hæd hæpənd. hi hæd wʌns hɝɾ ə ʃɪp kæptən spik ʌv ə dʒaɪən hæn hoʊldɪŋ ə hjudʒ kɹɪstəl sfɪɹ; beɪl doʊmən hæd kleɪmd ɪt stʌk aʊɾ ʌv ə hɪl ɑn ði aɪlən ə tʃɹɛmælkɪŋ.

Unsummoned, the void formed, whole and complete in an instant, saidin glowing, beckoning. So intent was he on the face and the hand that he did not even realize what had happened. He had once heard a ship captain speak of a giant hand holding a huge crystal sphere; Bayle Domon had claimed it stuck out of a hill on the island of Tremalking.

"ðɪs ɪz deɪnʒɝəs," səlin sɛd. "kʌm əweɪ, ɹænd."

"This is dangerous," Selene said. "Come away, Rand."

"aɪ bɪliv aɪ kən faɪn ə weɪ daʊn ðɛɹ," hi sɛɾ æbsənli. seɪɾɪn sæŋ tə hɪm. ðə hjudʒ bɔl sim tə ɡloʊ waɪt wɪð ðə laɪɾ ə ðə sɪŋkɪŋ sʌn. ɪt sim tə hɪm ðəɾ ɪn ðə dɛpθs ə ðə kɹɪstəl, laɪt swɝld ən dænst ɪn taɪm tə ðə sɔŋ ə seɪɾɪn. hi wʌndɝd waɪ ðə mɛn bɪloʊ dɪd nɑɾ əpɪɹ tə noʊɾəs.

"I believe I can find a way down there," he said absently. Saidin sang to him. The huge ball seemed to glow white with the light of the sinking sun. It seemed to him that in the depths of the crystal, light swirled and danced in time to the song of saidin. He wondered why the men below did not appear to notice.

səlin ɹoʊd kloʊs ən tʊk hoʊld ə hɪz ɑɹm. "pliz, ɹænd, jə mʌs kʌm əweɪ." hi lʊkt əɾ əɹ hænd, pʌzəld, ðən fɑloʊɾ əɹ ɑɹm ʌp tə hɝ feɪs. ʃi sim dʒɛnjəwənli wɝid, pɝhæps ivən əfɹeɪd. "ɪf ðɪs bæŋk dʌznt ɡɪv weɪ bɪniθ əɹ hɔɹsəz ən bɹeɪk əɹ nɛks wɪð ðə fɔl, ðoʊz mɛn ɑɹ ɡɑɹdz, ən noʊ wʌn pʊts ɡɑɹdz ɑn sʌmθɪŋ ðeɪ wɪʃ ɛvɹi pæsɝbaɪ tə ɪɡzæmɪn. wʌt ɡʊd wɪl ɪt dʒju tə əvɔɪd feɪn, ɪf səm lɔɹdz ɡɑɹdz ɝɛs ju? kʌm əweɪ."

Selene rode close and took hold of his arm. "Please, Rand, you must come away." He looked at her hand, puzzled, then followed her arm up to her face. She seemed genuinely worried, perhaps even afraid. "If this bank doesn't give way beneath our horses and break our necks with the fall, those men are guards, and no one puts guards on something they wish every passerby to examine. What good will it do you to avoid Fain, if some lord's guards arrest you? Come away."

sʌɾənli - ə dʒɹɪftɪŋ, dɪstən θɔt - hi ɹilaɪz ðət ðə vɔɪd sɝaʊndəd hɪm. seɪɾɪn sæŋ, ən ðə sfɪɹ pʌlsd - ivən wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ, hi kəd fil ɪt - ən ðə θɔt keɪm ðəɾ ɪf i sæŋ ðə sɔŋ seɪɾɪn sæŋ, ðət hjudʒ stoʊn feɪs wəɾ oʊpən ɪts maʊθ ən sɪŋ wɪð hɪm. wɪð ɪm ən wɪð seɪɾɪn. ɔl wʌn.

Suddenly - a drifting, distant thought - he realized that the void surrounded him. Saidin sang, and the sphere pulsed - even without looking, he could feel it - and the thought came that if he sang the song saidin sang, that huge stone face would open its mouth and sing with him. With him and with saidin. All one.

"pliz, ɹænd," səlin sɛd. "aɪ wɪl ɡoʊ tə ðə vɪlədʒ wɪð ju. aɪ woʊn mɛnʃən ðə hɔɹn əɡɛn. oʊnli kʌm əweɪ!"

"Please, Rand," Selene said. "I will go to the village with you. I won't mention the Horn again. Only come away!"

hi ɹilis ðə vɔɪd . . . ən ɪt dɪd nɑt ɡoʊ. seɪɾɪn kɹund, ən ðə laɪɾ ɪn ðə sfɪɹ bit laɪk ə hɑɹt. laɪk ɪz hɑɹt. lɔɪəl, hʊɹɪn, səlin, ðeɪ ɔl stɛɹɾ ət hɪm, bʌt ðeɪ simd əblɪviəs tə ðə ɡlɔɹiəs bleɪz fɹəm ðə kɹɪstəl. hi tʃɹaɪd tə pʊʃ ðə vɔɪɾ əweɪ. ɪt hɛld laɪk ɡɹænət; hi floʊɾəd ɪn ən ɛmptinəs əz hɑɹɾ əz stoʊn. ðə sɔŋ ə seɪɾɪn, ðə sɔŋ ə ðə sfɪɹ, hi kəd fil əm kwɪvɝɪŋ əlɔŋ ɪz boʊnz. ɡɹɪmli, hi ɹəfjuz tə ɡɪv ɪn, ɹitʃt dip ɪnsaɪd hɪmsɛlf . . . əl nɑt. . . .

He released the void . . . and it did not go. Saidin crooned, and the light in the sphere beat like a heart. Like his heart. Loial, Hurin, Selene, they all stared at him, but they seemed oblivious to the glorious blaze from the crystal. He tried to push the void away. It held like granite; he floated in an emptiness as hard as stone. The song of saidin, the song of the sphere, he could feel them quivering along his bones. Grimly, he refused to give in, reached deep inside himself . . . I will not. . . .

"ɹænd." hi dɪd nɑt noʊ huz vɔɪs ɪt wɑz.

"Rand." He did not know whose voice it was.

. . . ɹitʃt fəɹ ðə kɔɹ ə hu hi wɑz, ðə kɔɹ ʌv wʌɾ i wɑz . . .

. . . reached for the core of who he was, the core of what he was . . .

. . . wɪl nɑt . . .

. . . will not . . .

"ɹænd." ðə sɔŋ fɪl hɪm, fɪl ði ɛmptinəs.

"Rand." The song filled him, filled the emptiness.

. . . tʌtʃt stoʊn, hɑt fɹəm ə pɪɾiləs sʌn, koʊl fɹəm ə mɝsələs naɪt. . . .

. . . touched stone, hot from a pitiless sun, cold from a merciless night. . . .

. . . nɑt . . .

. . . not . . .

laɪt fɪl hɪm, blaɪndɪd hɪm.

Light filled him, blinded him.

"tɪl ʃeɪɾ ɪz ɡɔn," hi mʌmbəld, "tɪl wɔɾɝ ɪz ɡɔn . . ."

"Till shade is gone," he mumbled, "till water is gone . . ."

paʊɝ fɪl hɪm. hi wɑz wʌn wɪð ðə sfɪɹ.

Power filled him. He was one with the sphere.

". . . ɪndə ðə ʃædoʊ wɪð tiθ bɛɹd . . ."

". . . into the Shadow with teeth bared . . ."

ðə paʊɝ wɑz hɪz. ðə paʊɝ wɑz hɪz.

The power was his. The Power was his.

". . . tə spɪɾ ɪn saɪtblɪndɝz aɪ . . ."

". . . to spit in Sightblinder's eye . . ."

paʊɝ tə bɹeɪk ðə wɝld.

Power to Break the World.

". . . ɑn ðə læs deɪ!" ɪt keɪm aʊɾ əz ə ʃaʊt, ən ðə vɔɪd wɑz ɡɔn. ɹɛd ʃaɪɾ əɾ ɪz kɹaɪ; kleɪ kɹʌmbəld ʌndɝ ðə stæljənz huf, spɪlɪŋ ɪndə ðə pɪt. ðə bɪɡ beɪ wɛn tə hɪz niz. ɹænd lin fɔɹwɝd, ɡæðɝɪŋ ðə ɹeɪnz, ən ɹɛd skɹæmbəl tə seɪfti, əweɪ fɹəm ði ɛdʒ.

". . . on the last day!" It came out as a shout, and the void was gone. Red shied at his cry; clay crumbled under the stallion's hoof, spilling into the pit. The big bay went to his knees. Rand leaned forward, gathering the reins, and Red scrambled to safety, away from the edge.

ðeɪ wɝ ɔl stɛɹɪŋ ət hɪm, hi sɔ. səlin, lɔɪəl, hʊɹɪn, ɔl ə ðɛm. "wʌt hæpənd?" ðə vɔɪd. . . . hi tʌtʃt ɪz fɔɹhɛd. ðə vɔɪd hæd nɑt ɡɔn wən i ɹilist ɪt, ən ðə ɡloʊ ʌv seɪɾɪn hæd ɡɹoʊn stʃɹɔŋɝ, ænd. . . . hi kəd nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɛniθɪŋ mɔɹ. seɪɾɪn. hi fɛl koʊld. "dɪɾ aɪ . . . də sʌmθɪŋ?" hi fɹaʊnd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ. "dɪɾ aɪ seɪ sʌmθɪŋ?"

They were all staring at him, he saw. Selene, Loial, Hurin, all of them. "What happened?" The void. . . . He touched his forehead. The void had not gone when he released it, and the glow of saidin had grown stronger, and. . . . He could not remember anything more. Saidin. He felt cold. "Did I . . . do something?" He frowned, trying to remember. "Did I say something?"

"ju dʒʌst sæt ðəɹ stɪf əz ə stætʃu," lɔɪəl sɛd, "mʌmbəlɪŋ tə jɝsɛlf noʊ mæɾɝ wʌɾ ɛniwʌn sɛd. aɪ kʊdn meɪk aʊt wʌt jə wɝ seɪɪŋ, nɑɾ əntɪl jə ʃaʊɾəd 'deɪ!' laʊɾ ɪnʌf tə weɪk ðə dɛɾ ən nɪɹli pʊt jəɹ hɔɹs oʊvɝ ði ɛdʒ. ɑɹ jə ɪl? jəɹ æktɪŋ mɔɹ ən mɔɹ ɑdli ɛvɹi deɪ."

"You just sat there stiff as a statue," Loial said, "mumbling to yourself no matter what anyone said. I couldn't make out what you were saying, not until you shouted 'day!' loud enough to wake the dead and nearly put your horse over the edge. Are you ill? You're acting more and more oddly every day."

"aɪm nɑt sɪk," ɹænd sɛd hɑɹʃli, ðən sɔfən ɪt. "aɪ æm ɔl ɹaɪt, lɔɪəl." səlin wɑtʃt ɪm wɛɹəli.

"I'm not sick," Rand said harshly, then softened it. "I am all right, Loial." Selene watched him warily.

fɹəm ðə pɪt keɪm ðə saʊn ə mɛn kɔlɪŋ, ðə wɝdz ɪndɪstɪŋɡwɪʃəbəl.

From the pit came the sound of men calling, the words indistinguishable.

"lɔɹd ɹænd," hʊɹɪn sɛd, "aɪ θɪŋk ðoʊz ɡɑɹdz əv faɪnəli noʊɾəst ʌs. ɪf ðeɪ noʊ ə weɪ ʌp ðɪs saɪd, ðeɪ kəd bi hɪɹ ɛni mɪnət."

"Lord Rand," Hurin said, "I think those guards have finally noticed us. If they know a way up this side, they could be here any minute."

"jɛs," səlin sɛd. "lɛɾ əs liv hɪɹ kwɪkli."

"Yes," Selene said. "Let us leave here quickly."

ɹænd ɡlænst ət ði ɛkskəveɪʃən, ðən əweɪ əɡɛn, kwɪkli. ðə ɡɹeɪt kɹɪstəl hɛl nʌθɪŋ ɪksɛpt ɹəflɛktəd laɪt fɹəm ði ivnɪŋ sʌn, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt wɑnə lʊk əɾ ɪt. hi kəɾ ɔlmoʊst ɹɪmɛmbɝ . . . sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ðə sfɪɹ. "aɪ doʊn si ɛni ɹizən tə weɪt fəɹ ðɛm. wi dɪdn də ɛniθɪŋ. lɛts faɪn ən ɪn." hi tɝn ɹɛd təwɔɹd ðə vɪlədʒ, ən ðeɪ sun lɛf pɪɾ ən ʃaʊɾɪŋ ɡɑɹdz bɪhaɪnd.

Rand glanced at the excavation, then away again, quickly. The great crystal held nothing except reflected light from the evening sun, but he did not want to look at it. He could almost remember . . . something about the sphere. "I don't see any reason to wait for them. We didn't do anything. Let's find an inn." He turned Red toward the village, and they soon left pit and shouting guards behind.

əz mɛni vɪlədʒəz dɪd, tʃɹɛmoʊnzin kʌvɝd ðə tɑp ʌv ə hɪl, bʌt laɪk ðə fɑɹmz ðeɪ hæd pæst, ðɪs hɪl hæd bɪn skʌlptɪɾ ɪndə tɛɹəsəz wɪð stoʊn ɹɪteɪnɪŋ wɔlz. skwɛɹ stoʊn haʊsəz sæɾ ɑn pɹɪsaɪs plɑts ə lænd, wɪð ɪɡzækt ɡɑɹɾənz bɪhaɪnd, əlɔŋ ə fju stʃɹeɪt stʃɹits ðət kɹɔst itʃ ʌðɝ ət ɹaɪɾ æŋɡəlz. ðə nəsɛsəɾi ʌv ə kɝv tə stʃɹits ɡoʊɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə hɪl sim bɪɡɹʌdʒd.

As many villages did, Tremonsien covered the top of a hill, but like the farms they had passed, this hill had been sculpted into terraces with stone retaining walls. Square stone houses sat on precise plots of land, with exact gardens behind, along a few straight streets that crossed each other at right angles. The necessity of a curve to streets going around the hill seemed begrudged.

jɛt ðə pipəl simd oʊpən ən fɹɛnli ɪnʌf, pɔzɪŋ tə nɑd tə itʃ ʌðɝ əz ðeɪ hɝiɾ əbaʊt ðɛɹ læs tʃɔɹz bɪfɔɹ naɪtfɔl. ðeɪ wɝ ə ʃɔɹt foʊk - nʌn tɔlɝ ðən ɹændz ʃoʊldɝ, ən fju əz tɔl əz hʊɹɪn - wɪð dɑɹk aɪz ən peɪl, nɛɹoʊ feɪsəz, ən dʒɹɛst ɪn dɑɹk kloʊðz ɪksɛp fəɹ ə fju hu wɔɹ slæʃɪz ə kʌlɝ əkɹɔs ðə tʃɛst. smɛlz ə kʊkɪŋ - ɑdli spaɪst, tə ɹændz noʊz - fɪl ði ɛɹ, ðoʊ ə hændfʊl ʌv ɡʊdwaɪvz stɪl hʌŋ oʊvɝ ðɛɹ dɔɹz tə tɔk; ðə dɔɹz wɝ splɪt, soʊ ðə tɑp kəd stæn oʊpən waɪl ðə bɑɾəm wɑz kloʊzd. ðə pipəl aɪd ðə nukʌmɝz kjʊɹiəsli, wɪð noʊ saɪn ə hɑstɪləɾi. ə fju stɛɹɾ ə moʊmən lɔŋɡɝ ət lɔɪəl, ən oʊɡiɝ wɔkɪŋ əlɔŋsaɪɾ ə hɔɹs əz bɪɡ əz ə dɝən stæljən, bʌt nɛvɝ mɔɹ ðən ə moʊmən lɔŋɡɝ.

Yet the people seemed open and friendly enough, pausing to nod to each other as they hurried about their last chores before nightfall. They were a short folk - none taller than Rand's shoulder, and few as tall as Hurin - with dark eyes and pale, narrow faces, and dressed in dark clothes except for a few who wore slashes of color across the chest. Smells of cooking - oddly spiced, to Rand's nose - filled the air, though a handful of goodwives still hung over their doors to talk; the doors were split, so the top could stand open while the bottom was closed. The people eyed the newcomers curiously, with no sign of hostility. A few stared a moment longer at Loial, an Ogier walking alongside a horse as big as a Dhurran stallion, but never more than a moment longer.

ði ɪn, ət ðə vɛɹi tɑp ə ðə hɪl, wɑz stoʊn laɪk ɛvɹi ʌðɝ bɪldɪŋ ɪn ðə taʊn, ən pleɪnli mɑɹk baɪ ə peɪntəd saɪn hæŋɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə waɪd dɔɹz. ðə naɪn ɹɪŋz. ɹænd swʌŋ daʊn wɪð ə smaɪl ən taɪd ɹɛd tə wʌn ə ðə hɪtʃɪŋ poʊsts aʊt fɹʌnt. "ðə naɪn ɹɪŋz" hæd bɪn wʌn ə hɪz feɪvɹɪɾ ædvɛntʃɝ stɔɹiz wən i wɑz ə bɔɪ; hi səpoʊzd ɪt stɪl wɑz.

The inn, at the very top of the hill, was stone like every other building in the town, and plainly marked by a painted sign hanging over the wide doors. The Nine Rings. Rand swung down with a smile and tied Red to one of the hitching posts out front. "The Nine Rings" had been one of his favorite adventure stories when he was a boy; he supposed it still was.

səlin stɪl simd ənizi wən i hɛlpt əɹ dɪsmaʊnt. "ɑɹ jə ɔl ɹaɪt?" hi æskt. "aɪ dɪdn fɹaɪɾən jə bæk ðɛɹ, dɪɾ aɪ? ɹɛd wəd nɛvɝ fɔl oʊvɝ ə klɪf wɪð mi." hi wʌndɝd wʌt hæd ɹɪli hæpənd.

Selene still seemed uneasy when he helped her dismount. "Are you all right?" he asked. "I didn't frighten you back there, did I? Red would never fall over a cliff with me." He wondered what had really happened.

"ju tɛɹəfaɪd mi," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə taɪt vɔɪs, "æn aɪ də nɑt fɹaɪɾən izəli. jə cʊɾə kɪl jɝsɛlf, kɪld. . . ." ʃi smuðd əɹ dʒɹɛs. "ɹaɪd wɪð mi. tənaɪt. naʊ. bɹɪŋ ðə hɔɹn, ən əl steɪ baɪ jəɹ saɪd fɝɛvɝ. θɪŋk ʌv ɪt. mi baɪ jəɹ saɪd, ən ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ ɪn jəɹ hænz. ən ðət wɪl oʊnli bi ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ, aɪ pɹɑməs. wʌt mɔɹ kəd jə æsk fɔɹ?"

"You terrified me," she said in a tight voice, "and I do not frighten easily. You could have killed yourself, killed. . . ." She smoothed her dress. "Ride with me. Tonight. Now. Bring the Horn, and I will stay by your side forever. Think of it. Me by your side, and the Horn of Valere in your hands. And that will only be the beginning, I promise. What more could you ask for?"

ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "aɪ kænt, səlin. ðə hɔɹn. . . ." hi lʊkt ɝaʊnd. ə mæn lʊkt aʊɾ ɪz wɪndoʊ əkɹɔs ðə weɪ, ðən twɪtʃt ðə kɝɾənz kloʊzd; ivnɪŋ dɑɹkən ðə stʃɹit, ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ wʌn ɛls ɪn saɪt naʊ ɪksɛp lɔɪəl ən hʊɹɪn. "ðə hɔɹn ɪz nɑt maɪn. aɪ toʊl jə ðæt." ʃi tɝn əɹ bæk ɑn hɪm, hɝ waɪt kloʊk wɔlɪŋ ɪm ɔf əz ɪfɛktɪvli əz bɹɪks.

Rand shook his head. "I can't, Selene. The Horn. . . ." He looked around. A man looked out his window across the way, then twitched the curtains closed; evening darkened the street, and there was no one else in sight now except Loial and Hurin. "The Horn is not mine. I told you that." She turned her back on him, her white cloak walling him off as effectively as bricks.


tʃæptɝ twɛntiwʌn


CHAPTER 21

ðə naɪn ɹɪŋz


The Nine Rings

ɹænd ɪkspɛktəd ðə kɑmən ɹum tə bi ɛmpti, sɪns ɪt wɑz nɪɹli sʌpɝtaɪm, bʌt hæf ə dʌzən mɛn kɹaʊɾəd wʌn teɪbəl, dɪsɪŋ əmʌŋ ðɛɹ dʒæks ʌv eɪl, ən ənʌðɝ sæt baɪ hɪmsɛlf oʊvɝ ə mil. ðoʊ ðə dɪsɝz kæɹid noʊ wɛpənz ɪn saɪɾ ən wɔɹ noʊ ɑɹmɝ, oʊnli pleɪn koʊts ən bɹitʃɪz ə dɑɹk blu, sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ðə weɪ ðeɪ hɛl ðɛmsɛlvz toʊld ɹænd ðeɪ wɝ soʊlʒɝz. hɪz aɪz wɛn tə ðə sɑlətɛɹi mæn. ən ɔfəsɝ, wɪð ðə tɑps ə hɪz haɪ buts tɝn daʊn, ən ɪz sɔɹd pɹɑpt əɡɛns ðə teɪbəl bɪsaɪɾ ɪz tʃɛɹ. ə sɪŋɡəl slæʃ ə ɹɛɾ ən wʌn ə jɛloʊ kɹɔs ðə tʃɛst ə ði ɔfəsɝz blu koʊt fɹəm ʃoʊldɝ tə ʃoʊldɝ, ən ðə fɹʌn ə hɪz hɛd wɑz ʃeɪvd, ðoʊ hɪz blæk hɛɹ hʌŋ lɔŋ ɪn ðə bæk. ðə soʊlʒɝz' hɛɹ wɑz klɪpt ʃɔɹt, əz ɪf ɪɾ ɔl hæd bɪn kʌɾ ʌndɝ ðə seɪm boʊl. ɔl sɛvən tɝn tə lʊk əz ɹænd ən ði ʌðɝz keɪm ɪn.

Rand expected the common room to be empty, since it was nearly suppertime, but half a dozen men crowded one table, dicing among their jacks of ale, and another sat by himself over a meal. Though the dicers carried no weapons in sight and wore no armor, only plain coats and breeches of dark blue, something about the way they held themselves told Rand they were soldiers. His eyes went to the solitary man. An officer, with the tops of his high boots turned down, and his sword propped against the table beside his chair. A single slash of red and one of yellow crossed the chest of the officer's blue coat from shoulder to shoulder, and the front of his head was shaved, though his black hair hung long in the back. The soldiers' hair was clipped short, as if it all had been cut under the same bowl. All seven turned to look as Rand and the others came in.

ði ɪnkipɝ wɑz ə lin wʊmən wɪð ə lɔŋ noʊz ən ɡɹeɪɪŋ hɛɹ, bʌɾ əɹ ɹɪŋkəlz sim pɑɹɾ ə hɝ ɹɛɾi smaɪl mɔɹ ðən ɛniθɪŋ ɛls. ʃi keɪm bʌsəlɪŋ ʌp, waɪpɪŋ əɹ hænz ɑn ə spɑtləs waɪɾ eɪpɹən. "ɡʊɾ ivən tə ju" - hɝ kwɪk aɪz tʊk ɪn ɹændz ɡoʊld-ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɹɛd koʊt, ən səlinz faɪn waɪt dʒɹɛs - "maɪ lɔɹd, maɪ leɪɾi. aɪm mɑɡlɪn mædwən, maɪ lɔɹd. bi wɛlkəm tə ðə naɪn ɹɪŋz. ən ən oʊɡiɝ. nɑt mɛni ʌv jəɹ kaɪn kʌm ðɪs weɪ, fɹɛn oʊɡiɝ. wəd jə bi ʌp fɹəm stɛɾɪŋ tsəfu, ðɛn?"

The innkeeper was a lean woman with a long nose and graying hair, but her wrinkles seemed part of her ready smile more than anything else. She came bustling up, wiping her hands on a spotless white apron. "Good even to you" - her quick eyes took in Rand's gold-embroidered red coat, and Selene's fine white dress - "my Lord, my Lady. I am Maglin Madwen, my Lord. Be welcome to The Nine Rings. And an Ogier. Not many of your kind come this way, friend Ogier. Would you be up from Stedding Tsofu, then?"

lɔɪəl mænədʒd ən ɑkwɝd hæf baʊ ʌndɝ ðə weɪɾ ə ðə tʃɛst. "noʊ, ɡʊɾ ɪnkipɝ. aɪ kʌm ði ʌðɝ weɪ, fɹəm ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz."

Loial managed an awkward half bow under the weight of the chest. "No, good innkeeper. I come the other way, from the Borderlands."

"fɹʌm ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz, jə seɪ. wɛl. ən ju, maɪ lɔɹd? fɝɡɪv mi fəɹ æskɪŋ, bʌt juv nɑt ðə lʊk ə ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz, ɪf jə doʊn maɪn maɪ seɪɪŋ ɪt."

"From the Borderlands, you say. Well. And you, my Lord? Forgive me for asking, but you've not the look of the Borderlands, if you don't mind my saying it."

"aɪm fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, mɪstʃɹəs mædwən, ɪn ændɝ." hi ɡlænst ət səlin - ʃi dɪd nɑt sim tə ədmɪɾ i ɪɡzɪstəd; hɝ lɛvəl lʊk bɛɹli ədmɪɾəd ðət ðə ɹum ɪɡzɪstəd, əɹ ɛniwʌn ɪn ɪt. "ðə leɪɾi səlin ɪz fɹəm kɛɹhin, fɹəm ðə kæpəɾəl, ən aɪm fɹəm ændɝ."

"I'm from the Two Rivers, Mistress Madwen, in Andor." He glanced at Selene - she did not seem to admit he existed; her level look barely admitted that the room existed, or anyone in it. "The Lady Selene is from Cairhien, from the capital, and I am from Andor."

"æz jə seɪ, maɪ lɔɹd." mɪstʃɹəs mædwənz ɡlæns flɪkɝd tə ɹændz sɔɹd; ðə bɹɑnz hɛɹənz wɝ pleɪn ɑn skæbɝɾ ən hɪlt. ʃi fɹaʊn slaɪtli, bʌɾ əɹ feɪs wɑz klɪɹ əɡɛn ɪn ə blɪŋk. "jul bi wɑntɪŋ ə mil fəɹ jɝsɛlf ən jəɹ bjuɾəfəl leɪɾi, ən jəɹ fɑloʊɝz. ən ɹumz, aɪ ɪkspɛkt. əl əv jəɹ hɔɹsəz sin tə. aɪv ə ɡʊd teɪbəl fəɹ ju, ɹaɪt ðɪs weɪ, ən pɔɹk wɪð jɛloʊ pɛpɝz ɑn ðə faɪɝ. wəd jə bi hʌntɪŋ ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ, ðɛn, maɪ lɔɹd, jə ən jəɹ leɪɾi?"

"As you say, my Lord." Mistress Madwen's glance flickered to Rand's sword; the bronze herons were plain on scabbard and hilt. She frowned slightly, but her face was clear again in a blink. "You'll be wanting a meal for yourself and your beautiful Lady, and your followers. And rooms, I expect. I'll have your horses seen to. I've a good table for you, right this way, and pork with yellow peppers on the fire. Would you be hunting the Horn of Valere, then, my Lord, you and your Lady?"

ɪn ði ækt ə fɑloʊɪŋ hɝ, ɹænd ɔlmoʊst stʌmbəld. "noʊ! waɪ wəd jə θɪŋk wi wɝ?"

In the act of following her, Rand almost stumbled. "No! Why would you think we were?"

"noʊ əfɛns, maɪ lɔɹd. wiv hæd tu θɹu hɪɹ ɔlɹɛɾi, ɔl pɑlɪʃt tə lʊk laɪk hɪɹoʊz - nɑt tə sədʒɛst ɛniθɪŋ ə ðə kaɪn əbaʊt ju, maɪ lɔɹd - ɪn ðə læs mʌnθ. nɑt mɛni stʃɹeɪnʒɝz kʌm hɪɹ, ɪksɛp tʃɹeɪɾɝz ʌp fɹəm ðə kæpəɾəl tə baɪ oʊts ən bɑɹli. aɪd nɑt səpoʊz ðə hʌn əz lɛft ɪljən, jɛt, bʌt meɪbi səm doʊn θɪŋk ðeɪ ɹɪli nid ðə blɛsɪŋ, ən ðəl ɡɛɾ ə dʒʌmp ɑn ði ʌðɝz baɪ mɪsɪŋ ɪt."

"No offense, my Lord. We've had two through here already, all polished to look like heroes - not to suggest anything of the kind about you, my Lord - in the last month. Not many strangers come here, except traders up from the capital to buy oats and barley. I'd not suppose the Hunt has left Illian, yet, but maybe some don't think they really need the blessing, and they'll get a jump on the others by missing it."

"wi ɑɹ nɑt hʌntɪŋ ðə hɔɹn, mɪstʃɹəs." ɹænd dɪd nɑt ɡlæns ət ðə bʌndəl ɪn lɔɪəlz ɑɹmz; ðə blæŋkət wɪð ɪts kʌlɝfəl stʃɹaɪps hʌŋ bʌntʃt oʊvɝ ði oʊɡiɝz θɪk ɑɹmz ən dɪsɡaɪz ðə tʃɛst wɛl. "wi ʃʊɹli ɑɹ nɑt. wəɹ ɑn əɹ weɪ tə ðə kæpəɾəl."

"We are not hunting the Horn, mistress." Rand did not glance at the bundle in Loial's arms; the blanket with its colorful stripes hung bunched over the Ogier's thick arms and disguised the chest well. "We surely are not. We are on our way to the capital."

"æz jə seɪ, maɪ lɔɹd. fɝɡɪv mi fəɹ æskɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪz jəɹ leɪɾi wɛl?"

"As you say, my Lord. Forgive me for asking, but is your Lady well?"

səlin lʊkt ət hɝ, ən spoʊk fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm. "aɪ æm kwaɪt wɛl." hɝ vɔɪs lɛft ə tʃɪl ɪn ði ɛɹ ðət staɪfəl tɔk fəɹ ə moʊmənt.

Selene looked at her, and spoke for the first time. "I am quite well." Her voice left a chill in the air that stifled talk for a moment.

"jɔɹ nɑt kɛɹhinɪn, mɪstʃɹəs mædwən," hʊɹɪn sɛd sʌɾənli. bɝɾənd daʊn wɪð ðɛɹ sæɾəlbæɡz ən ɹændz bʌndəl, hi lʊk laɪk ə wɔkɪŋ bæɡədʒ kɑɹt. "pɑɹɾən, bʌt jə doʊn saʊn ɪt."

"You're not Cairhienin, Mistress Madwen," Hurin said suddenly. Burdened down with their saddlebags and Rand's bundle, he looked like a walking baggage cart. "Pardon, but you don't sound it."

mɪstʃɹəs mædwənz aɪbɹaʊz ɹoʊz, ən ʃi ʃɑɾ ə ɡlæns ət ɹænd, ðən ɡɹɪnd. "aɪ ʃʊɾə noʊn jud lɛt jəɹ mæn spik fɹili, bʌɾ aɪv ɡɹoʊn juz tə - " hɝ ɡlæns dɑɹɾɪd təwɔɹd ði ɔfəsɝ, hu hæd ɡɔn bæk tə hɪz oʊn mil. "laɪt, noʊ, aɪm nɑt kɛɹhinɪn, bʌt fəɹ maɪ sɪnz, aɪ mɛɹid wʌn. twɛnti-θɹi jɪɹz aɪ lɪvd wɪð hɪm, ən wən i daɪɾ ɑn mi - ðə laɪt ʃaɪn ɑn ɪm - aɪ wɑz ɔl ɹɛɾi tə ɡoʊ bæk tə luɡɹd, bʌɾ i hæd ðə læs læf, hi dɪd. hi lɛf mi ði ɪn, ən ɪz bɹʌðɝ ðə mʌni, wən aɪ wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪt wəd bi ði ʌðɝ weɪ ɹaʊnd. tʃɹɪksəm ən skimɪŋ, bɛɹɪn wɑz, laɪk ɛvɹi mæn aɪv ɛvɝ noʊn, kɛɹhinɪn moʊst ʌv ɔl. wɪl jə bi siɾəd, maɪ lɔɹd? maɪ leɪɾi?"

Mistress Madwen's eyebrows rose, and she shot a glance at Rand, then grinned. "I should have known you'd let your man speak freely, but I've grown used to - " Her glance darted toward the officer, who had gone back to his own meal. "Light, no, I'm not Cairhienin, but for my sins, I married one. Twenty-three years I lived with him, and when he died on me - the Light shine on him - I was all ready to go back to Lugard, but he had the last laugh, he did. He left me the inn, and his brother the money, when I was sure it would be the other way round. Tricksome and scheming, Barin was, like every man I've ever known, Cairhienin most of all. Will you be seated, my Lord? My Lady?"

ði ɪnkipɝ ɡeɪv ə sɝpɹaɪz blɪŋk wən hʊɹɪn sæɾ ət teɪbəl wɪð əm - ən oʊɡiɝ, ɪt simd, wɑz wʌn θɪŋ, bʌt hʊɹɪn wɑz klɪɹli ə sɝvən ɪn əɹ aɪz. wɪð ənʌðɝ kwɪk lʊk ət ɹænd, ʃi bʌsəld ɔf tə ðə kɪtʃənz, ən sun sɝvɪŋ ɡɝlz keɪm wɪð ðɛɹ mil, ɡɪɡəlɪŋ ən stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə lɔɹɾ ən ðə leɪɾi, ən ði oʊɡiɝ, tɪl mɪstʃɹəs mædwən tʃeɪst əm bæk tə ðɛɹ wɝk.

The innkeeper gave a surprised blink when Hurin sat at table with them - an Ogier, it seemed, was one thing, but Hurin was clearly a servant in her eyes. With another quick look at Rand, she bustled off to the kitchens, and soon serving girls came with their meal, giggling and staring at the lord and the lady, and the Ogier, till Mistress Madwen chased them back to their work.

ət fɝst, ɹænd stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪz fud daʊtfəli. ðə pɔɹk wɑz kʌɾ ɪn smɔl bɪts, mɪkst wɪð lɔŋ stʃɹɪps ə jɛloʊ pɛpɝz, ən piz, ən ə nʌmbɝ ə vɛdʒtəbəlz ən θɪŋz i dɪd nɑt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz, ɔl ɪn səm sɔɹɾ ə klɪɹ, θɪk sɔs. ɪt smɛl swiɾ ən ʃɑɹp, boʊθ ət ðə seɪm taɪm. səlin oʊnli pɪkt ət hɝz, bʌt lɔɪəl wɑz iɾɪŋ wɪð ə wɪl.

At first, Rand stared at his food doubtfully. The pork was cut in small bits, mixed with long strips of yellow peppers, and peas, and a number of vegetables and things he did not recognize, all in some sort of clear, thick sauce. It smelled sweet and sharp, both at the same time. Selene only picked at hers, but Loial was eating with a will.

hʊɹɪn ɡɹɪn ət ɹænd oʊvɝ ɪz fɔɹk. "ðeɪ spaɪs ðɛɹ fuɾ ɑdli, kɛɹhinɪn du, lɔɹd ɹænd, bʌt fəɹ ɔl ðæt, ɪts nɑt bæd."

Hurin grinned at Rand over his fork. "They spice their food oddly, Cairhienin do, Lord Rand, but for all that, it's not bad."

"ɪt woʊn baɪt ju, ɹænd," lɔɪəl æɾəd.

"It won't bite you, Rand," Loial added.

ɹænd tʊk ə hɛzɪɾənt maʊθfʊl, ən ɔlmoʊst ɡæspt. ɪt teɪstəd dʒʌst əz ɪt smɛld, swiɾ ən ʃɑɹp təɡɛðɝ, ðə pɔɹk kɹɪsp ɑn ði aʊtsaɪɾ ən tɛndɝ ɪnsaɪd, ə dʌzən dɪfɹən fleɪvɝz, spaɪsəz, ɔl blɛndɪŋ ən kəntʃɹæstɪŋ. ɪt teɪstəd laɪk nʌθɪŋ i hæɾ ɛvɝ pʊɾ ɪn ɪz maʊθ bɪfɔɹ. ɪt teɪstəd wʌndɝfəl. hi klin ɪz pleɪt, ən wən mɪstʃɹəs mædwən ɹɪtɝnd wɪð ðə sɝvɪŋ ɡɝlz tə klɪɹ əweɪ, hi nɪɹli æsk fəɹ mɔɹ ðə weɪ lɔɪəl dɪd. səlinz wɑz stɪl hæf fʊl, bʌt ʃi moʊʃən kɝtli fəɹ wʌn ə ðə ɡɝlz tə teɪk ɪt.

Rand took a hesitant mouthful, and almost gasped. It tasted just as it smelled, sweet and sharp together, the pork crisp on the outside and tender inside, a dozen different flavors, spices, all blending and contrasting. It tasted like nothing he had ever put in his mouth before. It tasted wonderful. He cleaned his plate, and when Mistress Madwen returned with the serving girls to clear away, he nearly asked for more the way Loial did. Selene's was still half full, but she motioned curtly for one of the girls to take it.

"ə plɛʒɝ, fɹɛn oʊɡiɝ." ði ɪnkipɝ smaɪld. "ɪt teɪks ə lɑt tə fɪl ʌp wʌn ə ju. kætʃɹin, bɹɪŋ ənʌðɝ hɛlpɪŋ, ən bi kwɪk." wʌn ə ðə ɡɝlz dɑɹɾɪd əweɪ. mɪstʃɹəs mædwən tɝn əɹ smaɪl ɑn ɹænd. "maɪ lɔɹd, aɪ hæɾ ə mæn hɪɹ u pleɪd ðə bɪɾɝn, bʌɾ i mɛɹiɾ ə ɡɝl ɔf wʌn ə ðə fɑɹmz, ən ʃiz ɪm stʃɹʌmɪŋ ɹeɪnz bɪhaɪn ə plaʊ, naʊ. aɪ kʊdn hɛlp noʊɾɪsɪŋ wʌt lʊks laɪk ə flut keɪs stɪkɪŋ aʊɾ ə jəɹ mænz bʌndəl. sɪns maɪ mjuzɪʃənz ɡɔn, wəd jə lɛt jəɹ mæn feɪvɝ əs wɪð ə lɪɾəl mjuzɪk?"

"A pleasure, friend Ogier." The innkeeper smiled. "It takes a lot to fill up one of you. Catrine, bring another helping, and be quick." One of the girls darted away. Mistress Madwen turned her smile on Rand. "My Lord, I had a man here who played the bittern, but he married a girl off one of the farms, and she has him strumming reins behind a plow, now. I couldn't help noticing what looks like a flute case sticking out of your man's bundle. Since my musician's gone, would you let your man favor us with a little music?"

hʊɹɪn lʊkt ɪmbɛɹəst.

Hurin looked embarrassed.

"hi dʌzn pleɪ," ɹænd ɪkspleɪnd. "aɪ du."

"He doesn't play," Rand explained. "I do."

ðə wʊmən blɪŋkt. ɪɾ əpɪɹd lɔɹdz dɪd nɑt pleɪ ðə flut, ət lis nɑɾ ɪn kɛɹhin. "aɪ wɪðdʒɹɔ ðə ɹɪkwɛst, maɪ lɔɹd. laɪts oʊn tʃɹuθ, aɪ mɛnt noʊ əfɛns, aɪ əʃʊɹ ju. aɪd nɛvɝ æsk wʌn sətʃ əz jɝsɛlf tə bi pleɪɪŋ ɪn ə kɑmən ɹum."

The woman blinked. It appeared lords did not play the flute, at least not in Cairhien. "I withdraw the request, my Lord. Light's own truth, I meant no offense, I assure you. I'd never ask one such as yourself to be playing in a common room."

ɹænd hɛzɪteɪɾɪd oʊnli ə moʊmənt. ɪt hæd bɪn tu lɔŋ sɪns i hæd pɹæktəs ðə flut ɹæðɝ ðən ðə sɔɹd, ən ðə kɔɪnz ɪn ɪz paʊtʃ wəd nɑt læs fɝɛvɝ. wʌns i wɑz ɹɪɾ ə hɪz fænsi kloʊðz - wʌns i tɝn ðə hɔɹn oʊvɝ tə ɪŋtʃɹ ən ðə dæɡɝ oʊvɝ tə mæt - hi wəd nid ðə flut tə ɝn ɪz sʌpɝ əɡɛn waɪl i sɝtʃt fəɹ sʌmwɛɹ seɪf fɹəm ɛɛs sədaɪ. ən seɪf fɹəm maɪsɛlf? sʌmθɪŋ dɪd hæpən bæk ðɛɹ. wʌt?

Rand hesitated only a moment. It had been too long since he had practiced the flute rather than the sword, and the coins in his pouch would not last forever. Once he was rid of his fancy clothes - once he turned the Horn over to Ingtar and the dagger over to Mat - he would need the flute to earn his supper again while he searched for somewhere safe from Aes Sedai. And safe from myself? Something did happen back there. What?

"aɪ doʊn maɪnd," hi sɛd. "hʊɹɪn, hæn mi ðə keɪs. dʒʌst slaɪɾ ɪɾ aʊt." ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid tə ʃoʊ ə ɡlimənz kloʊk; ɪnʌf ənspoʊkən kwɛstʃənz ʃoʊn ɪn mɪstʃɹəs mædwənz dɑɹk aɪz əz ɪt wɑz.

"I don't mind," he said. "Hurin, hand me the case. Just slide it out." There was no need to show a gleeman's cloak; enough unspoken questions shone in Mistress Madwen's dark eyes as it was.

wɝkt ɡoʊl tʃeɪst wɪð sɪlvɝ, ði ɪnstʃɹəmən lʊk ðə sɔɹɾ ə lɔɹd maɪt pleɪ, ɪf lɔɹdz ɛniwɛɹ pleɪd ðə flut. ðə hɛɹən bɹændɪɾ ɑn ɪz ɹaɪt pɑm dɪd nɑɾ ɪntɝfɪɹ wɪð ɪz fɪŋɡɝɪŋ. səlinz sɑvz hæd wɝk soʊ wɛl i hɑɹdli θɔɾ ə ðə bɹæn ənlɛs i sɔ ɪt. jɛɾ ɪt wɑz ɪn ɪz θɔts naʊ, ən ʌnkɑnʃəsli hi bɪɡæn tə pleɪ "hɛɹən ɑn ðə wɪŋ."

Worked gold chased with silver, the instrument looked the sort a lord might play, if lords anywhere played the flute. The heron branded on his right palm did not interfere with his fingering. Selene's salves had worked so well he hardly thought of the brand unless he saw it. Yet it was in his thoughts now, and unconsciously he began to play "Heron on the Wing."

hʊɹɪn bɑbd ɪz hɛd tə ðə tun, ən lɔɪəl bit taɪm ɑn ðə teɪbəl wɪð ə θɪk fɪŋɡɝ. səlin lʊkt ət ɹænd əz ɪf wʌndɝɪŋ wʌɾ i wɑz - aɪm nɑɾ ə lɔɹd, maɪ leɪɾi. ɪm ə ʃɛpɝd, ən aɪ pleɪ ðə fluɾ ɪn kɑmən ɹumz - bʌt ðə soʊlʒɝz tɝn fɹəm ðɛɹ tɔk tə lɪsən, ən ði ɔfəsɝ kloʊz ðə wʊɾən kʌvɝ ə ðə bʊk i hæd bɪɡʌn ɹɛɾɪŋ. səlinz stɛɾi ɡeɪz stʃɹʌk ə stʌbɝn spɑɹk ɪnsaɪd ɹænd. dətɝmənədli hi əvɔɪɾəd ɛni sɔŋ ðət maɪt fɪɾ ɪn ə pæləs, əɹ ə lɔɹdz mænɝ. hi pleɪd "oʊnli wʌn bʌkəɾ ʌv wɔɾɝ" ən "ði oʊl tu ɹɪvɝz lif," "oʊl dʒæks ʌp ə tʃɹi" ən "ɡʊdmən pɹəkəts paɪp."

Hurin bobbed his head to the tune, and Loial beat time on the table with a thick finger. Selene looked at Rand as if wondering what he was - I'm not a lord, my Lady. I'm a shepherd, and I play the flute in common rooms - but the soldiers turned from their talk to listen, and the officer closed the wooden cover of the book he had begun reading. Selene's steady gaze struck a stubborn spark inside Rand. Determinedly he avoided any song that might fit in a palace, or a lord's manor. He played "Only One Bucket of Water" and "The Old Two Rivers Leaf," "Old Jak's Up a Tree" and "Goodman Priket's Pipe."

wɪð ðə læst, ðə sɪks soʊlʒɝz bɪɡæn tə sɪŋ ɪn ɹɔkəs toʊnz, ðoʊ nɑt ðə wɝdz ɹænd nu.

With the last, the six soldiers began to sing in raucous tones, though not the words Rand knew.

"wi ɹoʊd daʊn tə ɹɪvɝ aɪɹælɛl dʒʌs tə si ðə tɛɹən kʌm.

"We rode down to River Iralell just to see the Tairen come.

wi stʊɾ əlɔŋ ðə ɹɪvɝbæŋk wɪð ðə ɹaɪzɪŋ ə ðə sʌn.

We stood along the riverbank with the rising of the sun.

ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz blæk ðə sʌmɝ pleɪn, ðɛɹ bænɝz blæk ðə skaɪ.

Their horses blacked the summer plain, their banners blacked the sky.

bʌt wi stʊɾ əɹ ɡɹaʊn ɑn ðə bæŋks ə ɹɪvɝ aɪɹælɛl.

But we stood our ground on the banks of River Iralell.

oʊ, wi stʊɾ əɹ ɡɹaʊnd.

Oh, we stood our ground.

jɛs, wi stʊɾ əɹ ɡɹaʊnd.

Yes, we stood our ground.

stʊɾ əɹ ɡɹaʊn əlɔŋ ðə ɹɪvɝ ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ."

Stood our ground along the river in the morning."

ɪt wɑz nɑt ðə fɝs taɪm ðət ɹænd hæd dɪskʌvɝɾ ə tun hæd dɪfɹənt wɝdz ən dɪfɹənt neɪmz ɪn dɪfɹən lænz, səmtaɪmz ivən ɪn vɪlədʒəz ɪn ðə seɪm lænd. hi pleɪɾ əlɔŋ wɪð əm əntɪl ðeɪ lɛt ðə wɝdz daɪ əweɪ, slæpɪŋ itʃ ʌðɝz ʃoʊldɝz ən meɪkɪŋ ɹud kɑmɛns ɑn wʌn ənʌðɝz sɪŋɪŋ.

It was not the first time that Rand had discovered a tune had different words and different names in different lands, sometimes even in villages in the same land. He played along with them until they let the words die away, slapping each other's shoulders and making rude comments on one another's singing.

wən ɹænd loʊɝd ðə flut, ði ɔfəsɝ ɹoʊz ən meɪɾ ə ʃɑɹp dʒɛstʃɝ. ðə soʊlʒɝz fɛl saɪlən ɪn mɪd-læf, skɹeɪp bæk ðɛɹ tʃɛɹz tə baʊ tə ði ɔfəsɝ wɪð hæn ɑn bɹɛst - ən tə ɹænd - ən lɛft wɪθaʊɾ ə bækwɝdz lʊk.

When Rand lowered the flute, the officer rose and made a sharp gesture. The soldiers fell silent in mid-laugh, scraped back their chairs to bow to the officer with hand on breast - and to Rand - and left without a backwards look.

ði ɔfəsɝ keɪm tə ɹændz teɪbəl ən baʊd, hæn tə hɑɹt; ðə ʃeɪvən fɹʌn ə hɪz hɛd lʊkt əz ɪf i hæd dʌstɪɾ ɪt wɪð waɪt paʊɾɝ. "ɡɹeɪs feɪvɝ ju, maɪ lɔɹd. aɪ tʃɹʌs ðeɪ dɪd nɑt bɑðɝ ju, sɪŋɪŋ əz ðeɪ dɪd. ðeɪ ɑɹ ə kɑmən sɔɹt, bʌt ðeɪ mɛnt noʊ ɪnsəlt, aɪ əʃʊɹ ju. aɪm ɔlʒɹɪn kɔldɛvwɪn, maɪ lɔɹd. kæptən ɪn ɪz mædʒəstiz sɝvəs, ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin hɪm." hɪz aɪz slɪɾ oʊvɝ ɹændz sɔɹd; ɹænd hæd ðə filɪŋ kɔldɛvwɪn hæd noʊɾəst ðə hɛɹənz əz sun əz i keɪm ɪn.

The officer came to Rand's table and bowed, hand to heart; the shaven front of his head looked as if he had dusted it with white powder. "Grace favor you, my Lord. I trust they did not bother you, singing as they did. They are a common sort, but they meant no insult, I assure you. I am Aldrin Caldevwin, my Lord. Captain in His Majesty's Service, the Light illumine him." His eyes slid over Rand's sword; Rand had the feeling Caldevwin had noticed the herons as soon as he came in.

"ðeɪ dɪdn ɪnsəl mi." ði ɔfəsɝz æksɛn ɹimaɪndəɾ ɪm ə mɔɪɹeɪnz, pɹɪsaɪs ən ɛvɹi wɝd pɹənaʊns tə ɪts fʊl. dɪd ʃi ɹɪli lemi ɡoʊ? aɪ wʌndɝ ɪf ʃiz fɑloʊɪŋ mi. əɹ weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ mi. "sɪt daʊn, kæptən. pliz." kɔldɛvwɪn dʒɹu ə tʃɛɹ fɹəm ənʌðɝ teɪbəl. "tɛl mi, kæptən, ɪf jə doʊn maɪnd. hæv jə sin ɛni ʌðɝ stʃɹeɪnʒɝz ɹisənli? ə leɪɾi, ʃɔɹɾ ən slɛndɝ, ən ə faɪɾɪŋ mæn wɪð blu aɪz. hiz tɔl, ən səmtaɪmz i wɛɹz ɪz sɔɹɾ ɑn ɪz bæk."

"They didn't insult me." The officer's accent reminded him of Moiraine's, precise and every word pronounced to its full. Did she really let me go? I wonder if she's following me. Or waiting for me. "Sit down, Captain. Please." Caldevwin drew a chair from another table. "Tell me, Captain, if you don't mind. Have you seen any other strangers recently? A lady, short and slender, and a fighting man with blue eyes. He's tall, and sometimes he wears his sword on his back."

"aɪ hæv sin noʊ stʃɹeɪnʒɝz əɾ ɔl," hi sɛd, loʊɝɪŋ hɪmsɛlf stɪfli tə hɪz sit. "seɪvɪŋ jɝsɛlf ən jəɹ leɪɾi, maɪ lɔɹd. fju ʌv ðə noʊbɪləɾi ɛvɝ kʌm hɪɹ." hɪz aɪz flɪk təwɔɹd lɔɪəl wɪð ə mɪnət fɹaʊn; hʊɹɪn i ɪɡnɔɹd fəɹ ə sɝvənt.

"I have seen no strangers at all," he said, lowering himself stiffly to his seat. "Saving yourself and your Lady, my Lord. Few of the nobility ever come here." His eyes flicked toward Loial with a minute frown; Hurin he ignored for a servant.

"ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə θɔt."

"It was only a thought."

"ʌndɝ ðə laɪt, maɪ lɔɹd, aɪ min noʊ dɪsɹɪspɛkt, bʌt meɪ aɪ hɪɹ jəɹ neɪm? wɪv soʊ fju stʃɹeɪnʒɝz hɪɹ ðəɾ aɪ faɪn aɪ wɪʃ tə noʊ ɛvɹi wʌn."

"Under the Light, my Lord, I mean no disrespect, but may I hear your name? We have so few strangers here that I find I wish to know every one."

ɹænd ɡeɪv ɪt - hi kleɪm noʊ taɪɾəl, bʌt ði ɔfəsɝ sim nɑt tə noʊɾəs - ən sɛɾ əz i hæd tə ði ɪnkipɝ, "fɹʌm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, ɪn ændɝ."

Rand gave it - he claimed no title, but the officer seemed not to notice - and said as he had to the innkeeper, "From the Two Rivers, in Andor."

"ə wʌnʒɹəs pleɪs aɪ hæv hɝd, lɔɹd ɹænd - aɪ meɪ kɔl jə soʊ? - ən faɪn mɛn, ði ændɝmən. noʊ kɛɹhinɪn əz ɛvɝ wɔɹn ə bleɪdmæstɝz sɔɹd soʊ jʌŋ əz ju. aɪ mɛt səm ændɝmən, wʌns, ðə kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl ə ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz əmʌŋ ðɛm. aɪ də nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɪz neɪm; ən ɪmbɛɹəsmənt. pɝhæps jə kəd feɪvɝ mi wɪð ɪt?"

"A wondrous place I have heard, Lord Rand - I may call you so? - and fine men, the Andormen. No Cairhienin has ever worn a blademaster's sword so young as you. I met some Andormen, once, the Captain-General of the Queen's Guards among them. I do not remember his name; an embarrassment. Perhaps you could favor me with it?"

ɹænd wɑz kɑnʃəs ə ðə sɝvɪŋ ɡɝlz ɪn ðə bækɡɹaʊnd, bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə klin ən swip. kɔldɛvwɪn simd oʊnli tə bi meɪkɪŋ kɑnvɝseɪʃən, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ə pɹoʊbɪŋ kwɑləɾi tə hɪz lʊk. "ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn."

Rand was conscious of the serving girls in the background, beginning to clean and sweep. Caldevwin seemed only to be making conversation, but there was a probing quality to his look. "Gareth Bryne."

"ʌv kɔɹs. jʌŋ, tə hoʊl soʊ mʌtʃ ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi."

"Of course. Young, to hold so much responsibility."

ɹænd kɛpt ɪz vɔɪs lɛvəl. "ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn əz ɪnʌf ɡɹeɪ ɪn ɪz hɛɹ tə bi jəɹ fɑðɝ, kæptən."

Rand kept his voice level. "Gareth Bryne has enough gray in his hair to be your father, Captain."

"fɝɡɪv mi, maɪ lɔɹd ɹænd. aɪ mɛn tə seɪ ðəɾ i keɪm tə ɪt jʌŋ." kɔldɛvwɪn tɝn tə səlin, ən fəɹ ə moʊmən i oʊnli stɛɹd. hi ʃʊk hɪmsɛlf, faɪnəli, əz ɪf kʌmɪŋ aʊɾ ʌv ə tʃɹæns. "fɝɡɪv mi fəɹ lʊkɪŋ ət jə soʊ, maɪ leɪɾi, ən fɝɡɪv mi fəɹ spikɪŋ soʊ, bʌt ɡɹeɪs əz ʃʊɹli feɪvɝd ju. wɪl jə ɡɪmi ə neɪm tə pʊt tə sətʃ bjuɾi?"

"Forgive me, my Lord Rand. I meant to say that he came to it young." Caldevwin turned to Selene, and for a moment he only stared. He shook himself, finally, as if coming out of a trance. "Forgive me for looking at you so, my Lady, and forgive me for speaking so, but Grace has surely favored you. Will you give me a name to put to such beauty?"

dʒʌst əz səlin oʊpən əɹ maʊθ, wʌn ə ðə sɝvɪŋ ɡɝlz lɛɾ aʊɾ ə kɹaɪ ən dʒɹɑpt ə læmp ʃi wɑz teɪkɪŋ daʊn fɹəm ə ʃɛlf. ɔɪl splæɾɝd, ən kɑɾ ɪn ə pul ə fleɪm ɑn ðə flɔɹ. ɹænd lɛp tə hɪz fiɾ əlɔŋ wɪð ði ʌðɝz ət ðə teɪbəl, bʌt bɪfɔɹ ɛni ʌv əm kəd muv, mɪstʃɹəs mædwən əpɪɹd, ən ʃi ən ðə ɡɝl smʌðɝd ðə fleɪmz wɪð ðɛɹ eɪpɹənz.

Just as Selene opened her mouth, one of the serving girls let out a cry and dropped a lamp she was taking down from a shelf. Oil splattered, and caught in a pool of flame on the floor. Rand leaped to his feet along with the others at the table, but before any of them could move, Mistress Madwen appeared, and she and the girl smothered the flames with their aprons.

"aɪ hæv toʊl jə tə bi kɛɹfəl, kætʃɹin," ði ɪnkipɝ sɛd, ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ naʊ-smʌɾi eɪpɹən ʌndɝ ðə ɡɝlz noʊz. "jul bi bɝnɪŋ ði ɪn daʊn, ən jɝsɛlf ɪn ɪt."

"I have told you to be careful, Catrine," the innkeeper said, shaking her now-smutty apron under the girl's nose. "You'll be burning the inn down, and yourself in it."

ðə ɡɝl simd ɑn ðə pɔɪn ə tɪɹz. "aɪ wɑz biɪŋ kɛɹfəl, mɪstʃɹəs, bʌɾ aɪ hæd sətʃ ə twɪnʒ ɪn maɪ ɑɹm."

The girl seemed on the point of tears. "I was being careful, Mistress, but I had such a twinge in my arm."

mɪstʃɹəs mædwən θɹu ʌp əɹ hænz. "ju ɔlweɪz əv səm ɪkskjus, ən jə stɪl bɹeɪk mɔɹ dɪʃəz ðən ɔl ðə ɹɛst. ɑ, ɪts ɔl ɹaɪt. klin ɪɾ ʌp, ən doʊn bɝn jɝsɛlf." ði ɪnkipɝ tɝn tə ɹænd ən ði ʌðɝz, ɔl stɪl stændɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə teɪbəl. "aɪ hoʊp nʌn ə jə teɪk ðɪs əmɪs. ðə ɡɝl ɹɪli woʊn bɝn daʊn ði ɪn. ʃiz hɑɹɾ ɑn ðə dɪʃəz wən ʃi stɑɹts munɪŋ oʊvɝ səm jʌŋ fɛloʊ, bʌt ʃiz nɛvɝ mɪshændəld ə læmp bɪfɔɹ."

Mistress Madwen threw up her hands. "You always have some excuse, and you still break more dishes than all the rest. Ah, it's all right. Clean it up, and don't burn yourself." The innkeeper turned to Rand and the others, all still standing around the table. "I hope none of you take this amiss. The girl really won't burn down the inn. She's hard on the dishes when she starts mooning over some young fellow, but she's never mishandled a lamp before."

"aɪ wəd laɪk tə bi ʃoʊn tə maɪ ɹum. aɪ də nɑt fil wɛl æftɝ ɔl." səlin spoʊk ɪn kɛɹfəl toʊnz, əz ðoʊ ənsɝɾən ə hɝ stʌmək, bʌt dɪspaɪt ðət ʃi lʊkt ən saʊndəɾ əz kul ən kɑm əz ɛvɝ. "ðə dʒɝni, ən ðə faɪɝ."

"I would like to be shown to my room. I do not feel well after all." Selene spoke in careful tones, as though uncertain of her stomach, but despite that she looked and sounded as cool and calm as ever. "The journey, and the fire."

ði ɪnkipɝ klʌk laɪk ə mʌðɝ hɛn. "ʌv kɔɹs, maɪ leɪɾi. aɪ hæv ə faɪn ɹum fəɹ jə ən jəɹ lɔɹd. ʃæl aɪ fɛtʃ mʌðɝ kɛɹɛdwən? ʃiz ə faɪn hænd wɪð suðɪŋ ɝbz."

The innkeeper clucked like a mother hen. "Of course, my Lady. I have a fine room for you and your Lord. Shall I fetch Mother Caredwain? She has a fine hand with soothing herbs."

səlinz vɔɪs ʃɑɹpənd. "noʊ. ən aɪ wɪʃ ə ɹum baɪ maɪsɛlf."

Selene's voice sharpened. "No. And I wish a room by myself."

mɪstʃɹəs mædwən ɡlænst ət ɹænd, bʌt ðə nɛks moʊmənt ʃi wɑz boʊɪŋ səlin səlɪsəɾəsli təwɔɹd ðə stɛɹz. "æz jə wɪʃ, maɪ leɪɾi. laɪɾən, fɛtʃ ðə leɪɾiz θɪŋz laɪk ə ɡʊd ɡɝl, naʊ." wʌn ə ðə sɝvɪŋ ɡɝlz ɹæn tə teɪk səlinz sæɾəlbæɡz fɹəm hʊɹɪn, ən ðə wɪmən dɪsəpɪɹɾ əpstɛɹz, səlin stɪf-bækt ən saɪlənt.

Mistress Madwen glanced at Rand, but the next moment she was bowing Selene solicitously toward the stairs. "As you wish, my Lady. Lidan, fetch the Lady's things like a good girl, now." One of the serving girls ran to take Selene's saddlebags from Hurin, and the women disappeared upstairs, Selene stiff-backed and silent.

kɔldɛvwɪn stɛɹɾ æftɝ əm əntɪl ðeɪ wɝ ɡɔn, ðən ʃʊk hɪmsɛlf əɡɛn. hi weɪɾəd əntɪl ɹænd hæd siɾəd hɪmsɛlf bɪfɔɹ teɪkɪŋ ɪz tʃɛɹ əɡɛn. "fɝɡɪv mi, maɪ lɔɹd ɹænd, fəɹ stɛɹɪŋ soʊ ət jəɹ leɪɾi, bʌt ɡɹeɪs əz ʃʊɹli feɪvɝd jə ɪn hɝ. aɪ min noʊ ɪnsəlt."

Caldevwin stared after them until they were gone, then shook himself again. He waited until Rand had seated himself before taking his chair again. "Forgive me, my Lord Rand, for staring so at your Lady, but Grace has surely favored you in her. I mean no insult."

"nʌn teɪkən," ɹænd sɛd. hi wʌndɝɾ ɪf ɛvɹi mæn fɛl ðə weɪ hi dɪd wən ðeɪ lʊkt ət səlin. "æz aɪ wɑz ɹaɪɾɪŋ tə ðə vɪlədʒ, kæptən, aɪ sɔ ə hjudʒ sfɪɹ. kɹɪstəl, ɪt simd. wʌɾ ɪz ɪt?"

"None taken," Rand said. He wondered if every man felt the way he did when they looked at Selene. "As I was riding to the village, Captain, I saw a huge sphere. Crystal, it seemed. What is it?"

ðə kɛɹhinɪnz aɪz ʃɑɹpənd. "ɪɾ ɪz pɑɹɾ ə ðə stætʃu, maɪ lɔɹd ɹænd," hi sɛd sloʊli. hɪz ɡeɪz flɪkɝd təwɔɹd lɔɪəl; fəɹ ən ɪnstən i sim tə bi kənsɪɾɝɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ nu.

The Cairhienin's eyes sharpened. "It is part of the statue, my Lord Rand," he said slowly. His gaze flickered toward Loial; for an instant he seemed to be considering something new.

"stætʃu? aɪ sɔ ə hænd, ən ə feɪs, tu. ɪt mʌs bi hjudʒ."

"Statue? I saw a hand, and a face, too. It must be huge."

"ɪɾ ɪz, maɪ lɔɹd ɹænd. ən oʊld." kɔldɛvwɪn pɔzd. "fɹʌm ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz, soʊ aɪm toʊld."

"It is, my Lord Rand. And old." Caldevwin paused. "From the Age of Legends, so I am told."

ɹænd fɛlt ə tʃɪl. ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz, wən jus ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ wɑz ɛvɹiwɛɹ, ɪf ðə stɔɹiz kəd bi bɪlivd. wʌt hæpən ðɛɹ? aɪ noʊ ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ.

Rand felt a chill. The Age of Legends, when use of the One Power was everywhere, if the stories could be believed. What happened there? I know there was something.

"ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz," lɔɪəl sɛd. "jɛs, ɪt mʌs bi. noʊ wʌn əz dʌn wɝk soʊ væst sɪns. ə ɡɹeɪt pis ʌv wɝk tə dɪɡ ðəɾ ʌp, kæptən." hʊɹɪn sæt saɪlənli, əz ɪf i nɑɾ oʊnli wɑz nɑt lɪsnɪŋ, bʌt wɑz nɑt ðəɹ əɾ ɔl.

"The Age of Legends," Loial said. "Yes, it must be. No one has done work so vast since. A great piece of work to dig that up, Captain." Hurin sat silently, as if he not only was not listening, but was not there at all.

kɔldɛvwɪn nɑɾəd ɹɪlʌktənli. "aɪ hæv faɪv hʌnʒɹəd leɪbɝɝz ɪn kæmp bɪɑn ðə dɪɡɪŋz, ən ivən soʊ ɪɾəl bi pæst sʌmɝz ɛn bɪfɔɹ wɪv ɪt klɪɹ. ðeɪ ɑɹ mɛn fɹəm ðə fɔɹɡeɪt. hæf maɪ wɝk ɪz tə kip əm dɪɡɪŋ, ən ði ʌðɝ hæf tə kip əm aʊɾ ə ðɪs vɪlədʒ. fɔɹɡeɪɾɝz əv ə fɑndnəs fəɹ dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ ən kəɹaʊzəŋ, jə ʌndɝstænd, ən ðiz pipəl lɛd kwaɪət lɪvz." hɪz toʊn sɛɾ ɪz sɪmpəθiz wɝ ɔl wɪð ðə vɪlɪdʒɝz.

Caldevwin nodded reluctantly. "I have five hundred laborers in camp beyond the diggings, and even so it will be past summer's end before we have it clear. They are men from the Foregate. Half my work is to keep them digging, and the other half to keep them out of this village. Foregaters have a fondness for drinking and carousing, you understand, and these people lead quiet lives." His tone said his sympathies were all with the villagers.

ɹænd nɑɾəd. hi hæd noʊ ɪntʃɹəst ɪn fɔɹɡeɪɾɝz, huɛvɝ ðeɪ wɝ. "wʌt wɪl jə də wɪð ɪt?" ðə kæptən hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, bʌt ɹænd oʊnli lʊk bæk əɾ ɪm əntɪl i spoʊk.

Rand nodded. He had no interest in Foregaters, whoever they were. "What will you do with it?" The captain hesitated, but Rand only looked back at him until he spoke.

"ɡɔlʒɹiən hɪmsɛlf əz ɔɹɾɝd ðəɾ ɪt bi teɪkən tə ðə kæpəɾəl."

"Galldrian himself has ordered that it be taken to the capital."

lɔɪəl blɪŋkt. "ə vɛɹi ɡɹeɪt pis ʌv wɝk, ðæt. aɪm nɑt ʃʊɹ haʊ sʌmθɪŋ ðət bɪɡ kəd bi muv soʊ fɑɹ."

Loial blinked. "A very great piece of work, that. I am not sure how something that big could be moved so far."

"hɪz mædʒəsti hæz ɔɹɾɝd ɪt," kɔldɛvwɪn sɛd ʃɑɹpli. "ɪt wɪl bi sɛɾ ʌp aʊtsaɪd ðə sɪɾi, ə mɑnjəmən tə ðə ɡɹeɪtnəs ə kɛɹhin ən ə haʊs ɹieɪɾən. oʊɡiɝ ɑɹ nɑt ði oʊnli wʌnz u noʊ haʊ tə muv stoʊn." lɔɪəl lʊkt əbæʃt, ən ðə kæptən vɪzəbli kɑm hɪmsɛlf. "jɔɹ pɑɹɾən, fɹɛn oʊɡiɝ. aɪ spoʊk ɪn heɪst, ən ɹudli." hi stɪl saʊndəɾ ə lɪɾəl ɡɹʌf. "wɪl jə bi steɪɪŋ ɪn tʃɹɛmoʊnzin lɔŋ, maɪ lɔɹd ɹænd?"

"His Majesty has ordered it," Caldevwin said sharply. "It will be set up outside the city, a monument to the greatness of Cairhien and of House Riatin. Ogier are not the only ones who know how to move stone." Loial looked abashed, and the captain visibly calmed himself. "Your pardon, friend Ogier. I spoke in haste, and rudely." He still sounded a little gruff. "Will you be staying in Tremonsien long, my Lord Rand?"

"wi liv ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ," ɹænd sɛd. "wi ɑɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə kɛɹhin."

"We leave in the morning," Rand said. "We are going to Cairhien."

"æz ɪt hæpənz, aɪm sɛndɪŋ səm ə maɪ mɛn bæk tə ðə sɪɾi təmɑɹoʊ. aɪ mʌst ɹoʊteɪt ðɛm; ðeɪ ɡɹoʊ steɪl æftɝ tu lɔŋ wɑtʃɪŋ mɛn swɪŋ pɪks ən ʃʌvəlz. jəl nɑt maɪn ɪf ðeɪ ɹaɪɾ ɪn jəɹ kʌmpəni?" hi pʊɾ ɪɾ əz ə kwɛstʃən, bʌɾ əz ɪf æksɛptəns wɝ ə fɔɹɡɔn kənkluʒən. mɪstʃɹəs mædwən əpɪɹɾ ɑn ðə stɛɹz, ən i ɹoʊz. "ɪf jəl ɪkskjuz mi, maɪ lɔɹd ɹænd, aɪ mʌs bi ʌp ɝli. əntɪl ðə mɔɹnɪŋ, ðɛn. ɡɹeɪs feɪvɝ ju." hi baʊd tə ɹænd, nɑɾəd tə lɔɪəl, ən lɛft.

"As it happens, I am sending some of my men back to the city tomorrow. I must rotate them; they grow stale after too long watching men swing picks and shovels. You will not mind if they ride in your company?" He put it as a question, but as if acceptance were a foregone conclusion. Mistress Madwen appeared on the stairs, and he rose. "If you will excuse me, my Lord Rand, I must be up early. Until the morning, then. Grace favor you." He bowed to Rand, nodded to Loial, and left.

əz ðə dɔɹz kloʊz bɪhaɪn ðə kɛɹhinɪn, ði ɪnkipɝ keɪm tə ðə teɪbəl.

As the doors closed behind the Cairhienin, the innkeeper came to the table.

"aɪ hæv jəɹ leɪɾi sɛɾəld, maɪ lɔɹd. ən aɪv ɡʊd ɹumz pɹipɛɹd fəɹ jə ən jəɹ mæn, ən ju, fɹɛn oʊɡiɝ." ʃi pɔzd, stʌɾiɪŋ ɹænd. "fɝɡɪv mi ɪf aɪ oʊvɝstɛp maɪsɛlf, maɪ lɔɹd, bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk aɪ kən spik fɹili tə ə lɔɹɾ u lɛts ɪz mæn spik ʌp. ɪf aɪm ɹɔŋ . . . wɛl, aɪ min noʊ ɪnsəlt. fəɹ twɛnti-θɹi jɪɹz bɛɹɪn mædwən ən aɪ wɝ ɑɹɡjuɪŋ wən wi wɝn kɪsɪŋ, soʊ tə spik. ðæts baɪ weɪ ʌv seɪɪŋ aɪ hæv səm ɪkspɪɹiəns. ɹaɪt naʊ, jəɹ θɪŋkɪŋ jəɹ leɪɾi nɛvɝ wɑns tə si jə əɡɛn, bʌɾ ɪts maɪ weɪ ʌv θɪŋkɪŋ ðəɾ ɪf jə tæp ɑn əɹ dɔɹ tənaɪt, ʃɪl bi teɪkɪŋ jə ɪn. smaɪl ən seɪ ɪt wɑz jəɹ fɔlt, wɛðɝ ɪt wɑz əɹ nɑt."

"I have your Lady settled, my Lord. And I've good rooms prepared for you and your man, and you, friend Ogier." She paused, studying Rand. "Forgive me if I overstep myself, my Lord, but I think I can speak freely to a lord who lets his man speak up. If I'm wrong . . . well, I mean no insult. For twenty-three years Barin Madwen and I were arguing when we weren't kissing, so to speak. That's by way of saying I have some experience. Right now, you're thinking your Lady never wants to see you again, but it's my way of thinking that if you tap on her door tonight, she'll be taking you in. Smile and say it was your fault, whether it was or not."

ɹænd klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊɾ ən hoʊpt ɪz feɪs wɑz nɑt tɝnɪŋ ɹɛd. laɪt, ɛɡwin wəd kɪl mi ɪf ʃi nu aɪɾ ivən θɔɾ ʌv ɪt. ən səlin wəd kɪl mi ɪf aɪ dɪɾ ɪt. əɹ wəd ʃi? ðət dɪd meɪk ɪz tʃiks bɝn. "aɪ . . . θæŋk jə fəɹ jəɹ sədʒɛstʃən, mɪstʃɹəs mædwən. ðə ɹumz. . . ." hi əvɔɪɾəd lʊkɪŋ ət ðə blæŋkət-kʌvɝd tʃɛs baɪ lɔɪəlz tʃɛɹ; ðeɪ dɪd nɑt dɛɹ liv ɪt wɪθaʊt sʌmwʌn əweɪk ən ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ɪt. "wi θɹi wɪl ɔl slip ɪn ðə seɪm ɹum."

Rand cleared his throat and hoped his face was not turning red. Light, Egwene would kill me if she knew I'd even thought of it. And Selene would kill me if I did it. Or would she? That did make his cheeks burn. "I . . . thank you for your suggestion, Mistress Madwen. The rooms. . . ." He avoided looking at the blanket-covered chest by Loial's chair; they did not dare leave it without someone awake and guarding it. "We three will all sleep in the same room."

ði ɪnkipɝ lʊk stɑɹɾəld, bʌt ʃi ɹəkʌvɝd kwɪkli. "æz jə wɪʃ, maɪ lɔɹd. ðɪs weɪ, ɪf jə pliz."

The innkeeper looked startled, but she recovered quickly. "As you wish, my Lord. This way, if you please."

ɹænd fɑloʊɾ əɹ ʌp ðə stɛɹz. lɔɪəl kæɹid ðə tʃɛst ʌndɝ ɪts blæŋkət - ðə stɛɹz ɡɹoʊn ʌndɝ ðə weɪɾ ə hɪm ən ðə tʃɛs təɡɛðɝ, bʌt ði ɪnkipɝ sim tə θɪŋk ɪt wɑz dʒʌst ən oʊɡiɝz bʌlk - ən hʊɹɪn stɪl kæɹiɾ ɔl ðə sæɾəlbæɡz ən ðə bʌndəl kloʊk wɪð ðə hɑɹp ən flut.

Rand followed her up the stairs. Loial carried the chest under its blanket - the stairs groaned under the weight of him and the chest together, but the innkeeper seemed to think it was just an Ogier's bulk - and Hurin still carried all the saddlebags and the bundled cloak with the harp and flute.

mɪstʃɹəs mædwən hæɾ ə θɝd bɛd bɹɔɾ ɪn ən heɪstəli əsɛmbəld ən meɪɾ ʌp. wʌn ə ðə bɛdz ɔlɹɛɾi ðəɹ stʃɹɛtʃt nɪɹli fɹəm wɔl tə wɔl ɪn lɛŋθ, ən hæɾ ɑbviəsli bɪn mɛn fəɹ lɔɪəl fɹəm ðə stɑɹt. ðəɹ wɑz bɛɹli ɹum tə wɔk bɪtwin ðə bɛdz. əz sun əz ði ɪnkipɝ wɑz ɡɔn, ɹænd tɝn tə ði ʌðɝz. lɔɪəl hæd pʊʃt ðə stɪl-kʌvɝd tʃɛst ʌndɝ ɪz bɛɾ ən wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ ðə mætʃɹəs. hʊɹɪn wɑz sɛɾɪŋ aʊt ðə sæɾəlbæɡz.

Mistress Madwen had a third bed brought in and hastily assembled and made up. One of the beds already there stretched nearly from wall to wall in length, and had obviously been meant for Loial from the start. There was barely room to walk between the beds. As soon as the innkeeper was gone, Rand turned to the others. Loial had pushed the still-covered chest under his bed and was trying the mattress. Hurin was setting out the saddlebags.

"du iðɝ ə jə noʊ waɪ ðət kæptən wɑz soʊ səspɪʃəs ʌv ʌs? hi wɑz, aɪm ʃʊɹ ʌv ɪt." hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "aɪ ɔlmoʊs θɪŋk i θɔt wi maɪt stil ðət stætʃu, ðə weɪ hi wɑz tɔkɪŋ."

"Do either of you know why that captain was so suspicious of us? He was, I'm sure of it." He shook his head. "I almost think he thought we might steal that statue, the way he was talking."

"deɪz deɪmɑɹ, lɔɹd ɹænd," hʊɹɪn sɛd. "ðə ɡɹeɪt ɡeɪm. ðə ɡeɪm ə haʊzɪz, səm kɔl ɪt. ðɪs kɔldɛvwɪn θɪŋks jə mʌs bi duɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ tə jəɹ ædvæntɪdʒ əɹ jə wʊdn bi hɪɹ. ən wʌtɛvɝ jəɹ duɪŋ maɪt bi tə hɪz dɪsədvæntɪdʒ, soʊ hiz tə bi kɛɹfəl."

"Daes Dae'mar, Lord Rand," Hurin said. "The Great Game. The Game of Houses, some call it. This Caldevwin thinks you must be doing something to your advantage or you wouldn't be here. And whatever you're doing might be to his disadvantage, so he has to be careful."

ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. " 'ðə ɡɹeɪt ɡeɪm'? wʌt ɡeɪm?"

Rand shook his head. " 'The Great Game'? What game?"

"ɪɾ ɪzən ə ɡeɪm əɾ ɔl, ɹænd," lɔɪəl sɛd fɹəm ɪz bɛd. hi hæd pʊld ə bʊk fɹəm ɪz pɑkət, bʌɾ ɪt leɪ ənoʊpən ɑn ɪz tʃɛst. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ mʌtʃ əbaʊɾ ɪt - oʊɡiɝ doʊn də sətʃ θɪŋz - bʌɾ aɪ hæv hɝɾ ʌv ɪt. ðə noʊbəlz ən ðə noʊbəl haʊsəz mənuvɝ fəɹ ædvæntɪdʒ. ðeɪ də θɪŋz ðeɪ θɪŋk wɪl hɛlp ðɛm, əɹ hɝɾ ən ɛnəmi, əɹ boʊθ. juʒəwəli, ɪts ɔl dʌn ɪn sikɹəsi, əɹ ɪf nɑt, ðeɪ tʃɹaɪ tə meɪk ɪt sim əz ɪf ðəɹ duɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ ʌðɝ ðən wʌt ðeɪ ɑɹ." hi ɡeɪv wʌn tʌftəɾ ɪɹ ə pʌzəl skɹætʃ. "ivən noʊɪŋ wʌɾ ɪɾ ɪz, aɪ doʊn ʌndɝstæn ɪt. ɛldɝ heɪmən ɔlweɪz sɛɾ ɪt wəd teɪk ə ɡɹeɪɾɝ maɪn ðən ɪz tə ʌndɝstæn ðə θɪŋz hjumənz du, ən aɪ doʊnt noʊ mɛni əz ɪntɛlədʒən əz ɛldɝ heɪmən. jə hjumənz ɑɹ ɑd."

"It isn't a game at all, Rand," Loial said from his bed. He had pulled a book from his pocket, but it lay unopened on his chest. "I don't know much about it - Ogier don't do such things - but I have heard of it. The nobles and the noble Houses maneuver for advantage. They do things they think will help them, or hurt an enemy, or both. Usually, it's all done in secrecy, or if not, they try to make it seem as if they're doing something other than what they are." He gave one tufted ear a puzzled scratch. "Even knowing what it is, I don't understand it. Elder Haman always said it would take a greater mind than his to understand the things humans do, and I don't know many as intelligent as Elder Haman. You humans are odd."

hʊɹɪn ɡeɪv ði oʊɡiɝ ə slæntəd lʊk, bʌɾ i sɛd, "hi hæz ðə ɹaɪɾ ə deɪz deɪmɑɹ, lɔɹd ɹænd. kɛɹhinɪn pleɪ ɪt mɔɹ ðən moʊst, ðoʊ ɔl sʌðɝnɝz du."

Hurin gave the Ogier a slanted look, but he said, "He has the right of Daes Dae'mar, Lord Rand. Cairhienin play it more than most, though all southerners do."

"ðiz soʊlʒɝz ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ," ɹænd sɛd. "ɑɹ ðeɪ pɑɹɾ ə kɔldɛvwɪn pleɪɪŋ ðɪs ɡɹeɪt ɡeɪm? wi kæn əfɔɹd tə ɡɛt mɪkst ɪn ɛniθɪŋ laɪk ðæt." ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid tə mɛnʃən ðə hɔɹn. ðeɪ wɝ ɔl tu əwɛɹ ʌv ɪts pɹɛzəns.

"These soldiers in the morning," Rand said. "Are they part of Caldevwin playing this Great Game? We can't afford to get mixed in anything like that." There was no need to mention the Horn. They were all too aware of its presence.

lɔɪəl ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ, ɹænd. hiz hjumən, soʊ ɪt kəd min ɛniθɪŋ."

Loial shook his head. "I don't know, Rand. He's human, so it could mean anything."

"hʊɹɪn?"

"Hurin?"

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ, iðɝ." hʊɹɪn saʊndəɾ əz wɝiɾ əz ði oʊɡiɝ lʊkt. "hi kəd bi duɪŋ dʒʌst wʌɾ i sɛd, ɔɹ. . . . ðæts ðə weɪ ʌv ðə ɡeɪm ə haʊsəz. jə nɛvɝ noʊ. aɪ spɛn moʊst ə maɪ taɪm ɪn kɛɹhin ɪn ðə fɔɹɡeɪt, lɔɹd ɹænd, ən aɪ doʊnt noʊ mʌtʃ əbaʊt kɛɹhinɪn noʊbəlz, bʌt - wɛl, deɪz deɪmɑɹ kən bi deɪnʒɝəs ɛniwɛɹ, bʌɾ ɪspɛʃli ɪn kɛɹhin, aɪv hɝd." hi bɹaɪɾənd sʌɾənli. "ðə leɪɾi səlin, lɔɹd ɹænd. ʃɪl noʊ bɛɾɝ ðən mi əɹ ðə bɪldɝ. jə kən æsk əɹ ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ."

"I don't know, either." Hurin sounded as worried as the Ogier looked. "He could be doing just what he said, or. . . . That's the way of the Game of Houses. You never know. I spent most of my time in Cairhien in the Foregate, Lord Rand, and I don't know much about Cairhienin nobles, but - well, Daes Dae'mar can be dangerous anywhere, but especially in Cairhien, I've heard." He brightened suddenly. "The Lady Selene, Lord Rand. She'll know better than me or the Builder. You can ask her in the morning."

bʌɾ ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ, səlin wɑz ɡɔn. wən ɹænd wɛn daʊn tə ðə kɑmən ɹum, mɪstʃɹəs mædwən hændəɾ ɪm ə sil pɑɹtʃmənt. "ɪf jəl fɝɡɪv mi, maɪ lɔɹd, jə ʃʊɾə lɪsən tə mi. jə ʃʊɾə tæpt ɑn jəɹ leɪɾiz dɔɹ."

But in the morning, Selene was gone. When Rand went down to the common room, Mistress Madwen handed him a sealed parchment. "If you'll forgive me, my Lord, you should have listened to me. You should have tapped on your Lady's door."

ɹænd weɪɾəd əntɪl ʃi wɛn əweɪ bɪfɔɹ i bɹoʊk ðə waɪt wæks sil. ðə wæks hæd bɪn ɪmpɹɛst wɪð ə kɹɛsən mun ən stɑɹz.

Rand waited until she went away before he broke the white wax seal. The wax had been impressed with a crescent moon and stars.

aɪ mʌs liv jə fəɹ ə taɪm. ðəɹ ɑɹ tu mɛni pipəl hɪɹ, ən aɪ də nɑt laɪk kɔldɛvwɪn. əl əweɪt jə ɪn kɛɹhin. nɛvɝ θɪŋk ðəɾ aɪm tu fɑɹ fɹəm ju. jəl bi ɪn maɪ θɔts ɔlweɪz, əz aɪ noʊ ðəɾ aɪm ɪn jʊɹz.

I must leave you for a time. There are too many people here, and I do not like Caldevwin. I will await you in Cairhien. Never think that I am too far from you. You will be in my thoughts always, as I know that I am in yours.

ɪt wɑz nɑt saɪnd, bʌt ðəɾ ɛləɡənt, floʊɪŋ skɹɪp hæd ðə lʊk ə səlin.

It was not signed, but that elegant, flowing script had the look of Selene.

hi foʊldəɾ ɪt kɛɹfəli ən pʊɾ ɪɾ ɪn ɪz pɑkət bɪfɔɹ ɡoʊɪŋ aʊtsaɪd, wɛɹ hʊɹɪn hæd ðə hɔɹsəz weɪɾɪŋ.

He folded it carefully and put it in his pocket before going outside, where Hurin had the horses waiting.

kæptən kɔldɛvwɪn wɑz ðɛɹ, tu, wɪð ənʌðɝ, jʌŋɡɝ ɔfəsɝ ən fɪfti maʊntəd soʊlʒɝz kɹaʊɾɪŋ ðə stʃɹit. ðə tu ɔfəsɝz wɝ bɛɹ-hɛɾəd, bʌt wɔɹ stil-bækt ɡɔnləts, ən ɡoʊld-wɝk bɹɛstpleɪts stʃɹæpt oʊvɝ ðɛɹ blu koʊts. ə ʃɔɹt stæf wɑz fæsən tə ðə hɑɹnəs ɑn itʃ ɔfəsɝz bæk, bɛɹɪŋ ə smɔl, stɪf blu bænɝ əbʌv ɪz hɛd. kɔldɛvwɪnz bænɝ bɔɹ ə sɪŋɡəl waɪt stɑɹ, waɪl ðə jʌŋɡɝ mænz wɑz kɹɔs baɪ tu waɪt bɑɹz. ðeɪ wɝ ə ʃɑɹp kɑntʃɹæs tə ðə soʊlʒɝz ɪn ðɛɹ pleɪn ɑɹmɝ ən hɛlməts ðət lʊk laɪk bɛlz wɪð mɛɾəl kʌɾ əweɪ tə ɪkspoʊz ðɛɹ feɪsəz.

Captain Caldevwin was there, too, with another, younger officer and fifty mounted soldiers crowding the street. The two officers were bare-headed, but wore steel-backed gauntlets, and gold-worked breastplates strapped over their blue coats. A short staff was fastened to the harness on each officer's back, bearing a small, stiff blue banner above his head. Caldevwin's banner bore a single white star, while the younger man's was crossed by two white bars. They were a sharp contrast to the soldiers in their plain armor and helmets that looked like bells with metal cut away to expose their faces.

kɔldɛvwɪn baʊɾ əz ɹænd keɪm aʊɾ ə ði ɪn. "ɡʊd mɔɹnɪŋ tə ju; maɪ lɔɹd ɹænd. ðɪs ɪz ɛlɹəkeɪn tɑvəlɪn, hu wɪl kəmæn jəɹ ɛskɔɹt, ɪf aɪ meɪ kɔl ɪt ðæt." ði ʌðɝ ɔfəsɝ baʊd; hɪz hɛd wɑz ʃeɪvd əz kɔldɛvwɪnz wɑz. hi dɪd nɑt spik.

Caldevwin bowed as Rand came out of the inn. "Good morning to you; my Lord Rand. This is Elricain Tavolin, who will command your escort, if I may call it that." The other officer bowed; his head was shaved as Caldevwin's was. He did not speak.

"æn ɛskɔɹt wɪl bi wɛlkəm, kæptən," ɹænd sɛd, mænɪdʒɪŋ tə saʊn əɾ iz. feɪn wəd nɑt tʃɹaɪ ɛniθɪŋ əɡɛns fɪfti soʊlʒɝz, bʌt ɹænd wɪʃt i kəd bi sɝɾən ðeɪ wɝ oʊnli ən ɛskɔɹt.

"An escort will be welcome, Captain," Rand said, managing to sound at ease. Fain would not try anything against fifty soldiers, but Rand wished he could be certain they were only an escort.

ðə kæptən aɪd lɔɪəl, ɑn ɪz weɪ tə hɪz hɔɹs wɪð ðə blæŋkət-kʌvɝd tʃɛst. "ə hɛvi bɝɾən, oʊɡiɝ."

The captain eyed Loial, on his way to his horse with the blanket-covered chest. "A heavy burden, Ogier."

lɔɪəl ɔlmoʊs mɪst ə stɛp. "aɪ nɛvɝ laɪk tə bi fɑɹ fɹəm maɪ bʊks, kæptən." hɪz waɪd maʊθ flæʃt tiθ ɪn ə sɛlf-kɑnʃəs ɡɹɪn, ən i hɝid tə stʃɹæp ðə tʃɛst ɑntu hɪz sæɾəl.
