"Burn him!" she sobbed. "The Light burn him! He has no right!" Within her she felt a flowering, an opening up, an unfolding to light.

tiθ bɛɹd, ʃi tɝn tə feɪs əɹ pɝsuɝ dʒʌst əz eɪdʒɪnɝ əpɪɹd, læfɪŋ, ɪn ə lɝtʃɪŋ ɡæləp.

Teeth bared, she turned to face her pursuer just as Aginor appeared, laughing, in a lurching gallop.

"ju hæv noʊ ɹaɪt!" ʃi flʌŋ əɹ fɪs təwɔɹd hɪm, fɪŋɡɝz oʊpənɪŋ əz ɪf ʃi wɝ θɹoʊɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ. ʃi wɑz oʊnli hæf sɝpɹaɪz tə si ə bɔl ə faɪɝ liv əɹ hænd.

"You have no right!" She flung her fist toward him, fingers opening as if she were throwing something. She was only half surprised to see a ball of fire leave her hand.

ɪɾ ɪksploʊɾəd əɡɛnst eɪdʒɪnɝz tʃɛst, nɑkɪŋ ɪm tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. fəɹ oʊnli ən ɪnstən i spɹɔl ðɛɹ, ðən ɹoʊz, stæɡɝɪŋ. hi simd ʌnəwɛɹ ə ðə smoʊldɝɪŋ fɹʌn ə hɪz koʊt. "ju dɛɹ? jə dɛɹ!" hi kwɪvɝd, ən spɪɾəl lik daʊn ɪz tʃɪn.

It exploded against Aginor's chest, knocking him to the ground. For only an instant he sprawled there, then rose, staggering. He seemed unaware of the smoldering front of his coat. "You dare? You dare!" He quivered, and spittle leaked down his chin.

əbɹʌpli ðəɹ wɝ klaʊdz ɪn ðə skaɪ, θɹɛɾənɪŋ bɪloʊz ʌv ɡɹeɪ ən blæk. laɪtnɪŋ lɛp fɹəm ðə klaʊd, stʃɹeɪt fəɹ nɪneɪivz hɑɹt.

Abruptly there were clouds in the sky, threatening billows of gray and black. Lightning leaped from the cloud, straight for Nynaeve's heart.

ɪt sim tə hɝ, dʒʌs fəɹ ə hɑɹtbit, əz ɪf taɪm hæd sʌɾənli sloʊd, əz ðoʊ ðət hɑɹtbit tʊk fɝɛvɝ. ʃi fɛl ðə floʊ ɪnsaɪɾ əɹ - seɪaɪdɑɹ, keɪm ə dɪstən θɔt - fɛl ði ænsɝɪŋ floʊ ɪn ðə laɪtnɪŋ. ən ʃi ɔltɝd ðə dɝɛkʃən ə ðə floʊ. taɪm lɛp fɔɹwɝd.

It seemed to her, just for a heartbeat, as if time had suddenly slowed, as though that heartbeat took forever. She felt the flow inside her - saidar, came a distant thought - felt the answering flow in the lightning. And she altered the direction of the flow. Time leaped forward.

wɪð ə kɹæʃ, ðə boʊlt ʃæɾɝd stoʊn əbʌv eɪdʒɪnɝz hɛd. ðə fɔɹseɪkənz sʌŋkən aɪz waɪɾənd, ən i tɑɾɝd bæk. "ju kænɑt! ɪt kænɑt bi!" hi lɛpt əweɪ əz laɪtnɪŋ stʃɹʌk wɛɹ i hæd stʊd, stoʊn ɪɹʌptɪŋ ɪn ə faʊntən ə ʃɑɹdz.

With a crash, the bolt shattered stone above Aginor's head. The Forsaken's sunken eyes widened, and he tottered back. "You cannot! It cannot be!" He leaped away as lightning struck where he had stood, stone erupting in a fountain of shards.

ɡɹɪmli nɪneɪiv stɑɹɾəd təwɔɹd hɪm. ən eɪdʒɪnɝ flɛd.

Grimly Nynaeve started toward him. And Aginor fled.

seɪaɪdɑɹ wɑz ə tɔɹən ɹeɪsɪŋ θɹu hɝ. ʃi kəd fil ðə ɹɑks ɝaʊn hɝ, ən ði ɛɹ, fil ðə taɪni, floʊɪŋ bɪts ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ ðət səfjuz ðɛm, ən meɪd ðɛm. ən ʃi kəd fil eɪdʒɪnɝ duɪŋ . . . sʌmθɪŋ, əz wɛl. dɪmli ʃi fɛlt ɪt, ən fɑɹ dɪstənt, əz ɪf ɪt wɝ sʌmθɪŋ ʃi kəd nɛvɝ tʃɹuli noʊ, bʌɾ ɝaʊn əɹ ʃi sɔ ði ɪfɛks ən nu ðɛm fəɹ wʌt ðeɪ wɝ.

Saidar was a torrent racing through her. She could feel the rocks around her, and the air, feel the tiny, flowing bits of the One Power that suffused them, and made them. And she could feel Aginor doing . . . something, as well. Dimly she felt it, and far distant, as if it were something she could never truly know, but around her she saw the effects and knew them for what they were.

ðə ɡɹaʊn ɹʌmbəld ən hivd ʌndɝ əɹ fit. wɔlz tɑpəld ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ, paɪlz ə stoʊn tə blɑk əɹ weɪ. ʃi skɹæmbəld oʊvɝ ðɛm, ənkɛɹɪŋ ɪf ʃɑɹp ɹɑk kʌt hænz ən fit, ɔlweɪz kipɪŋ eɪdʒɪnɝ ɪn saɪt. ə wɪn ɹoʊz, haʊlɪŋ daʊn ðə pæsədʒəz əɡɛns hɝ, ɹeɪdʒɪŋ tɪl ɪt flæɾənd əɹ tʃiks ən meɪɾ əɹ aɪz wɔɾɝ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə nɑk əɹ daʊn; ʃi tʃeɪnʒd ðə floʊ, ən eɪdʒɪnɝ tʌmbəld əlɔŋ ðə pæsədʒweɪ laɪk ən əpɹuɾɪd bʊʃ. ʃi tʌtʃt ðə floʊ ɪn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ɹiɾɝɛktɪd ɪt, ən stoʊn wɔlz kəlæpst ɝaʊn eɪdʒɪnɝ, silɪŋ ɪm ɪn. laɪtnɪŋ fɛl wɪð əɹ ɡlɛɹ, stʃɹaɪkɪŋ ɝaʊn hɪm, stoʊn ɪksploʊɾɪŋ ɛvɝ kloʊsɝ ən kloʊsɝ. ʃi kəd fil ɪm faɪɾɪŋ tə pʊʃ ɪt bæk ət hɝ, bʌt fʊt baɪ fʊt ðə dæzəlɪŋ boʊls muv təwɔɹd ðə fɔɹseɪkən.

The ground rumbled and heaved under her feet. Walls toppled in front of her, piles of stone to block her way. She scrambled over them, uncaring if sharp rock cut hands and feet, always keeping Aginor in sight. A wind rose, howling down the passages against her, raging till it flattened her cheeks and made her eyes water, trying to knock her down; she changed the flow, and Aginor tumbled along the passageway like an uprooted bush. She touched the flow in the ground, redirected it, and stone walls collapsed around Aginor, sealing him in. Lightning fell with her glare, striking around him, stone exploding ever closer and closer. She could feel him fighting to push it back at her, but foot by foot the dazzling bolts moved toward the Forsaken.

sʌmθɪŋ ɡlimd ɔf tə hɝ ɹaɪt, sʌmθɪŋ ənkʌvɝd baɪ ðə kəlæpsɪŋ wɔlz.

Something gleamed off to her right, something uncovered by the collapsing walls.

nɪneɪiv kəd fil eɪdʒɪnɝ wikənɪŋ, fil ɪz ɛfɝts tə stʃɹaɪk əɾ əɹ ɡɹoʊ mɔɹ fibəl ən mɔɹ fɹæntɪk. jɛt sʌmhaʊ ʃi nu hi hæd nɑt ɡɪvən ʌp. ɪf ʃi lɛɾ ɪm ɡoʊ naʊ, hi wəd tʃeɪs æftɝ əɹ əz stʃɹɔŋli əz bɪfɔɹ, kənvɪnst ʃi wɑz tu wik tə dɪfiɾ ɪm æftɝ ɔl, tu wik tə stɑp ɪm fɹəm duɪŋ wɪð əɹ əz i wɪʃt.

Nynaeve could feel Aginor weakening, feel his efforts to strike at her grow more feeble and more frantic. Yet somehow she knew he had not given up. If she let him go now, he would chase after her as strongly as before, convinced she was too weak to defeat him after all, too weak to stop him from doing with her as he wished.

ə sɪlvɝ ɑɹtʃ stʊd wɛɹ stoʊn hæd bɪn, ən ɑɹtʃ fɪld wɪð sɑf sɪlvɝ ɹeɪdʒjəns. ðə weɪ bæk. . . .

A silver arch stood where stone had been, an arch filled with soft silver radiance. The way back. . . .

ʃi nu wən ðə fɔɹseɪkən əbændən ɪz ətæk, ðə moʊmənt wən ɔl ɪz ɛfɝts wɝ ɡɪvən oʊvɝ tə steɪvɪŋ əɹ ɔf. ən ɪz paʊɝ wɑz nɑɾ ɪnʌf, hi kəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ dɪflɛkt əɹ bloʊz. naʊ hi hæd tə flɪŋ hɪmsɛlf əweɪ fɹəm ðə lipɪŋ ɡaʊts ə stoʊn θɹoʊn ʌp baɪ hɝ laɪtnɪŋ, ði ɪksploʊʒənz flɪŋɪŋ ɪm daʊn əɡɛn.

She knew when the Forsaken abandoned his attack, the moment when all his efforts were given over to staving her off. And his power was not enough, he could no longer deflect her blows. Now he had to fling himself away from the leaping gouts of stone thrown up by her lightning, the explosions flinging him down again.

ðə weɪ bæk wɪl kʌm bʌt wʌns. bi stɛdfæst.

The way back will come but once. Be steadfast.

ðə laɪtnɪŋ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ fɛl. nɪneɪiv tɝn fɹəm ðə skɹæbəlɪŋ eɪdʒɪnɝ tə lʊk ət ði ɑɹtʃ. ʃi lʊk bæk əɾ eɪdʒɪnɝ, dʒʌst ɪn taɪm tə si hɪm kɹɔl aʊɾ ə saɪɾ oʊvɝ ðə maʊndɪd stoʊn ən dɪsəpɪɹ. ʃi hɪst ɪn fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən. mʌtʃ ə ðə meɪz stɪl stʊd, ən ə hʌnʒɹəd nu pleɪsəz tə haɪɾ ɪn ðə ɹʌbəl ʃi ən ðə fɔɹseɪkən hæd meɪd. ɪt wəd teɪk taɪm tə faɪn ɪm əɡɛn, bʌt ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪf ʃi dɪd nɑt faɪn ɪm fɝst, hi wəd faɪn hɝ. ɪn ɪz fʊl stʃɹɛŋkθ, hi wəd kʌm ɑn əɹ wən ʃi list ɪkspɛktəd hɪm.

The lightning no longer fell. Nynaeve turned from the scrabbling Aginor to look at the arch. She looked back at Aginor, just in time to see him crawl out of sight over the mounded stone and disappear. She hissed in frustration. Much of the maze still stood, and a hundred new places to hide in the rubble she and the Forsaken had made. It would take time to find him again, but she was sure if she did not find him first, he would find her. In his full strength, he would come on her when she least expected him.

ðə weɪ bæk wɪl kʌm bʌt wʌns.

The way back will come but once.

fɹaɪɾənd, ʃi lʊkt əɡɛn ən wɑz ɹɪliv tə si ði ɑɹtʃ stɪl ðɛɹ. ɪf ʃi kəd faɪn eɪdʒɪnɝ kwɪkli. . . .

Frightened, she looked again and was relieved to see the arch still there. If she could find Aginor quickly. . . .

bi stɛdfæst.

Be steadfast.

wɪð ə kɹaɪ ʌv θwɔɹɾəd æŋɡɝ, ʃi klaɪmd oʊvɝ ðə tʌmbəl stoʊn təwɔɹd ði ɑɹtʃ. "huɛvɝz ɹispɑnsəbəl fəɹ mi biɪŋ hɪɹ," ʃi mʌɾɝd, "aɪl meɪk əm wɪʃ ðeɪ hæd ɡɑɾən wʌɾ eɪdʒɪnɝ ɡɑt. əl - " ʃi stɛpt ɪndə ði ɑɹtʃ, ən ðə laɪɾ oʊvɝwɛlm hɝ.

With a cry of thwarted anger, she climbed over the tumbled stone toward the arch. "Whoever's responsible for me being here," she muttered, "I'll make them wish they had gotten what Aginor got. I'll - " She stepped into the arch, and the light overwhelmed her.

"aɪl - " nɪneɪiv stɛpt aʊɾ ə ði ɑɹtʃ ən stɑp tə stɛɹ. ɪt wɑz ɔl əz ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝd - ðə sɪlvɝ tɛɹæŋɡɹil, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðə tʃeɪmbɝ - bʌt ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ wɑz laɪk ə bloʊ, æbsən mɛmɹiz kɹæʃɪŋ bæk ɪndə hɝ hɛd. ʃi hæd kʌm aʊɾ ə ðə seɪm ɑɹtʃ baɪ wɪtʃ ʃi wɛn ɪn.

"I'll - " Nynaeve stepped out of the arch and stopped to stare. It was all as she remembered - the silver ter'angreal, the Aes Sedai, the chamber - but remembering was like a blow, absent memories crashing back into her head. She had come out of the same arch by which she went in.

ðə ɹɛd sɪstɝ ɹeɪzd wʌn ə ðə sɪlvɝ tʃæləsəz haɪ ən pɔɹɾ ə stʃɹim ə kul, klɪɹ wɔɾɝ oʊvɝ nɪneɪivz hɛd. "ju ɑɹ wɑʃt klin ʌv wʌt sɪn jə meɪ hæv dʌn," ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪntoʊnd, "æn ə ðoʊz dʌn əɡɛns ju. jə ɑɹ wɑʃt klin ʌv wʌt kɹaɪm jə meɪ hæv kəmɪɾəd, ən ə ðoʊz kəmɪɾəd əɡɛns ju. jə kʌm tə əs wɑʃt klin ən pjʊɹ, ɪn hɑɹɾ ən soʊl."

The Red sister raised one of the silver chalices high and poured a stream of cool, clear water over Nynaeve's head. "You are washed clean of what sin you may have done," the Aes Sedai intoned, "and of those done against you. You are washed clean of what crime you may have committed, and of those committed against you. You come to us washed clean and pure, in heart and soul."

nɪneɪiv ʃɪvɝɾ əz ðə wɔɾɝ ɹæn daʊn əɹ bɑɾi, dʒɹɪpɪŋ ɑn ðə flɔɹ.

Nynaeve shivered as the water ran down her body, dripping on the floor.

ʃɛɹiəm tʊk əɹ ɑɹm wɪð ə ɹɪliv smaɪl, bʌt ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz' vɔɪs ɡeɪv noʊ hɪn ə pæst wɝi. "ju də wɛl soʊ fɑɹ. kʌmɪŋ bæk ɪz duɪŋ wɛl. ɹɪmɛmbɝ wʌt jəɹ pɝpəs ɪz, ən jəl kəntɪnju tə bi wɛl." ðə ɹɛdhɛd bɪɡæn tə liɾ əɹ ɝaʊn ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil tə ənʌðɝ ɑɹtʃ.

Sheriam took her arm with a relieved smile, but the Mistress of Novices' voice gave no hint of past worry. "You do well so far. Coming back is doing well. Remember what your purpose is, and you will continue to be well." The redhead began to lead her around the ter'angreal to another arch.

"ɪt wɑz soʊ ɹil," nɪneɪiv sɛɾ ɪn ə wɪspɝ. ʃi kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɛvɹiθɪŋ, ɹɪmɛmbɝ tʃænəlɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ əz izəli əz lɪftɪŋ əɹ hænd. ʃi kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ eɪdʒɪnɝ, ən ðə θɪŋz ðə fɔɹseɪkən wɑntəd tə də tə hɝ. ʃi ʃɪvɝɾ əɡɛn. "wɑz ɪt ɹil?"

"It was so real," Nynaeve said in a whisper. She could remember everything, remember channeling the One Power as easily as lifting her hand. She could remember Aginor, and the things the Forsaken wanted to do to her. She shivered again. "Was it real?"

"noʊ wʌn noʊz," ʃɛɹiəm ɹɪplaɪd. "ɪt simz ɹil ɪn mɛmɹi, ən səm əv kʌm aʊt bɛɹɪŋ ði æktʃəwəl wunz ə hɝts teɪkən ɪnsaɪd. ʌðɝz əv bɪn kʌt tə ðə boʊn ɪnsaɪd, ən kʌm bæk wɪθaʊɾ ə mɑɹk. ɪts ɔl ʌv ɪt dɪfɹən ɛvɹi taɪm fəɹ ɛvɹi wʊmən u ɡoʊz ɪn. ði eɪntʃəns sɛd ðəɹ wɝ mɛni wɝlz. pɝhæps ðɪs tɛɹæŋɡɹil teɪks jə tə ðɛm. jɛɾ ɪf soʊ, ɪt dʌz soʊ ʌndɝ vɛɹi stʃɹɪnʒənt ɹulz fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ mɛn dʒʌs tə teɪk jə fɹəm wʌn pleɪs tə ənʌðɝ. aɪ bɪliv ɪts nɑt ɹil. bʌt ɹɪmɛmbɝ, wɛðɝ wʌt hæpənz ɪz ɹil əɹ nɑt, ðə deɪnʒɝ ɪz əz ɹil əz ə naɪf plʌnʒɪŋ ɪndə jəɹ hɑɹt."

"No one knows," Sheriam replied. "It seems real in memory, and some have come out bearing the actual wounds of hurts taken inside. Others have been cut to the bone inside, and come back without a mark. It is all of it different every time for every woman who goes in. The ancients said there were many worlds. Perhaps this ter'angreal takes you to them. Yet if so, it does so under very stringent rules for something meant just to take you from one place to another. I believe it is not real. But remember, whether what happens is real or not, the danger is as real as a knife plunging into your heart."

"aɪ tʃænəl ðə paʊɝ. ɪt wɑz soʊ izi."

"I channeled the Power. It was so easy."

ʃɛɹiəm mɪst ə stɛp. "ðæɾ ɪzən səpoʊz tə bi pɑsəbəl. jə ʃəd nɑɾ ivən ɹɪmɛmbɝ biɪŋ eɪbəl tə tʃænəl." ʃi stʌɾid nɪneɪiv. "æn jɛt jə ɑɹ nɑt hɑɹmd. aɪ kən stɪl sɛns ði əbɪləɾi ɪn ju, əz stʃɹɔŋ əz ɪɾ ɛvɝ wɑz."

Sheriam missed a step. "That isn't supposed to be possible. You should not even remember being able to channel." She studied Nynaeve. "And yet you are not harmed. I can still sense the ability in you, as strong as it ever was."

"ju saʊn əz ɪf ɪt wɝ deɪnʒɝəs," nɪneɪiv sɛd sloʊli, ən ʃɛɹiəm hɛzɪteɪɾɪd bɪfɔɹ ænsɝɪŋ.

"You sound as if it were dangerous," Nynaeve said slowly, and Sheriam hesitated before answering.

"ɪɾ ɪzən θɔt nɛsəsɛɹi tə ɡɪv ə wɔɹnɪŋ, sɪns jə ʃʊdn bi eɪbəl tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɪt, bʌt. . . . ðɪs tɛɹæŋɡɹil wɑz faʊn dʊɹɪŋ ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz. wɪv ðə ɹɛkɝdz ʌv ɪts ɪɡzæməneɪʃən ɪn ði ɑɹkaɪvz. ðə fɝst sɪstɝ tə ɛntɝ wɑz wɔɹɾɪd əz stʃɹɔŋli əz ʃi kəd bi, sɪns noʊ wʌn nu wʌɾ ɪt wəd du. ʃi kɛpt əɹ mɛmɹiz, ən ʃi tʃænəl ðə wʌn paʊɝ wən ʃi wɑz θɹɛɾənd. ən ʃi keɪm aʊt wɪð əɹ əbɪləɾiz bɝn tə nʌθɪŋ, əneɪbəl tə tʃænəl, əneɪbəl ivən tə sɛns ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs. ðə sɛkən tə ɡoʊ ɪn wɑz ɔlsoʊ wɔɹɾɪd, ən ʃi, tu, wɑz dɪstʃɹɔɪɾ ɪn ðə seɪm weɪ. ðə θɝd wɛn ʌnpɹətɛktɪd, ɹɪmɛmbɝd nʌθɪŋ wʌns ʃi wɑz ɪnsaɪd, ən ɹɪtɝn ənhɑɹmd. ðəɾ ɪz wʌn ɹizən waɪ wi sɛn jə kəmplitli ʌnpɹətɛktɪd. nɪneɪiv, jə mʌs nɑt tʃænəl ɪnsaɪd ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil əɡɛn. aɪ noʊ ɪts hɑɹd tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɛniθɪŋ, bʌt tʃɹaɪ."

"It isn't thought necessary to give a warning, since you shouldn't be able to remember it, but. . . . This ter'angreal was found during the Trolloc Wars. We have the records of its examination in the archives. The first sister to enter was warded as strongly as she could be, since no one knew what it would do. She kept her memories, and she channeled the One Power when she was threatened. And she came out with her abilities burned to nothing, unable to channel, unable even to sense the True Source. The second to go in was also warded, and she, too, was destroyed in the same way. The third went unprotected, remembered nothing once she was inside, and returned unharmed. That is one reason why we send you completely unprotected. Nynaeve, you must not channel inside the ter'angreal again. I know it is hard to remember anything, but try."

nɪneɪiv swɑloʊd. ʃi kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɛvɹiθɪŋ, kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ. "aɪ woʊn tʃænəl," ʃi sɛd. ɪf aɪ kən ɹɪmɛmbɝ nɑt tə. ʃi wɑntəd tə læf hɪstɛɹɪkli.

Nynaeve swallowed. She could remember everything, could remember not remembering. "I won't channel," she said. If I can remember not to. She wanted to laugh hysterically.

ðeɪ hæd ɹitʃt ðə nɛkst ɑɹtʃ. ðə ɡloʊ stɪl fɪld əm ɔl. ʃɛɹiəm ɡeɪv nɪneɪiv ə læst wɔɹnɪŋ lʊk, ən lɛft əɹ stændɪŋ əloʊn.

They had reached the next arch. The glow still filled them all. Sheriam gave Nynaeve a last warning look, and left her standing alone.

"ðə sɛkən taɪm ɪz fəɹ wʌɾ ɪz. ðə weɪ bæk wɪl kʌm bʌt wʌns. bi stɛdfæst."

"The second time is for what is. The way back will come but once. Be steadfast."

nɪneɪiv stɛɹɾ ət ðə ʃaɪnɪŋ sɪlvɝ ɑɹtʃ. wʌɾ ɪz ɪn ðəɹ ðɪs taɪm? ði ʌðɝz wɝ weɪɾɪŋ, wɑtʃɪŋ. ʃi stɛp fɝmli θɹu ɪndə ðə laɪt.

Nynaeve stared at the shining silver arch. What is in there this time? The others were waiting, watching. She stepped firmly through into the light.

nɪneɪiv stɛɹd daʊn ət ðə pleɪn bɹaʊn dʒɹɛs ʃi wɔɹ wɪð sɝpɹaɪz, ðən ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt. waɪ wɑz ʃi stɛɹɪŋ əɾ əɹ oʊn dʒɹɛs? ðə weɪ bæk wɪl kʌm bʌt wʌns.

Nynaeve stared down at the plain brown dress she wore with surprise, then gave a start. Why was she staring at her own dress? The way back will come but once.

lʊkɪŋ ɝaʊn hɝ, ʃi smaɪld. ʃi stʊɾ ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə ðə ɡɹin ɪn ɛmənz fild, wɪð θætʃ-ɹuf haʊzɪz ɔl ɝaʊnd, ən ðə waɪnspɹɪŋ ɪn ɹaɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ. ðə waɪnspɹɪŋ ɪtsɛlf ɹoʊz ɪn ə ɡʌʃ fɹəm ðə stoʊn aʊtkɹɑp θɹʌstɪŋ ʌp θɹu ðə ɡɹæs ə ðə ɡɹin, ən ðə waɪn-spɹɪŋ wɔɾɝ ɹʌʃt ɔf ist ʌndɝ ðə wɪloʊz bɪsaɪd ði ɪn. ðə stʃɹits wɝ ɛmpti, bʌt moʊs pipəl wəd bi ət ðɛɹ tʃɔɹz ðɪs taɪm ə ðə mɔɹnɪŋ.

Looking around her, she smiled. She stood on the edge of the Green in Emond's Field, with thatch-roofed houses all around, and the Winespring Inn right in front of her. The Winespring itself rose in a gush from the stone outcrop thrusting up through the grass of the Green, and the Wine-spring Water rushed off east under the willows beside the inn. The streets were empty, but most people would be at their chores this time of the morning.

lʊkɪŋ ət ði ɪn, hɝ smaɪl feɪɾəd. ðəɹ wɑz mɔɹ ðən ən ɛɹ ə nəɡlɛkt əbaʊɾ ɪt, waɪtwɑʃ feɪɾəd, ə ʃʌɾɝ hæŋɪŋ lus, ðə ɹɑɾɪd ɛn ʌv ə ɹæftɝ ʃoʊɪŋ əɾ ə ɡæp ɪn ðə ɹuf taɪlz. wʌts ɡɑɾən ɪndə bɹæn? ɪz i spɛndɪŋ soʊ mʌtʃ taɪm biɪŋ meɪɝ hiz fɝɡɛɾɪŋ tə teɪk kɛɹ ə hɪz ɪn?

Looking at the inn, her smile faded. There was more than an air of neglect about it, whitewash faded, a shutter hanging loose, the rotted end of a rafter showing at a gap in the roof tiles. What's gotten into Bran? Is he spending so much time being Mayor he's forgetting to take care of his inn?

ði ɪn dɔɹ swʌŋ oʊpən, ən sɛn bui keɪm aʊt, stɑpɪŋ dɛd wən i sɔ hɝ. ði oʊl θætʃɝ wɑz əz nɑɹld əz ən oʊk ɹut, ən ðə lʊk i ɡeɪv əɹ wɑz dʒʌst əz fɹɛnli. "soʊ juv kʌm bæk, hæv ju? wɛl, jə maɪɾ əz wɛl bi ɔf əɡɛn."

The inn door swung open, and Cenn Buie came out, stopping dead when he saw her. The old thatcher was as gnarled as an oak root, and the look he gave her was just as friendly. "So you've come back, have you? Well, you might as well be off again."

ʃi fɹaʊn əz i spæɾ əɾ əɹ fiɾ ən hɝiɾ ɑn pæs hɝ; sɛn wɑz nɛvɝ ə plɛzən mæn, bʌɾ i wɑz sɛldəm oʊpənli ɹud. nɛvɝ tə hɝ, ət list. nɛvɝ tə hɝ feɪs. fɑloʊɪŋ ɪm wɪð əɹ aɪ, ʃi sɔ saɪnz ə nəɡlɛkt ɔl θɹu ðə vɪlədʒ, θætʃ ðət ʃʊɾə bɪn mɛndɪd, widz fɪlɪŋ jɑɹdz. ðə dɔɹ ɑn mɪstʃɹəs ɑlkɑɹz haʊs hʌŋ æslɑn ɑn ə bɹoʊkən hɪnʒ.

She frowned as he spat at her feet and hurried on past her; Cenn was never a pleasant man, but he was seldom openly rude. Never to her, at least. Never to her face. Following him with her eye, she saw signs of neglect all through the village, thatch that should have been mended, weeds filling yards. The door on Mistress al'Caar's house hung aslant on a broken hinge.

ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛd, nɪneɪiv pʊʃt ɪndə ði ɪn. əl əv mɔɹ ðən wʌn wɝd wɪð bɹæn əbaʊt ðɪs.

Shaking her head, Nynaeve pushed into the inn. I'll have more than one word with Bran about this.

ðə kɑmən ɹum wɑz ɛmpti ɪksɛp fəɹ ə loʊn wʊmən, hɝ θɪk, ɡɹeɪɪŋ bɹeɪd pʊld oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. ʃi wɑz waɪpɪŋ ə teɪbəl, bʌt fɹəm ðə weɪ ʃi stɛɹɾ ət ðə teɪbəltɑp, nɪneɪiv dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ʃi wɑz əwɛɹ ʌv wʌt ʃi duɪŋ. ðə ɹum sim dʌsti.

The common room was empty except for a lone woman, her thick, graying braid pulled over her shoulder. She was wiping a table, but from the way she stared at the tabletop, Nynaeve did not think she was aware of what she doing. The room seemed dusty.

"mɛɹɪn?"

"Marin?"

mɛɹɪn ælvɪɹ dʒʌmpt, wʌn hæn klʌtʃɪŋ əɹ θɹoʊt, ən stɛɹd. ʃi lʊk jɪɹz oʊldɝ ðən nɪneɪiv ɹɪmɛmbɝd. wɔɹn. "nɪneɪiv? nɪneɪiv! oʊ, ɪts ju. ɛɡwin? hæv jə bɹɔɾ ɛɡwin bæk? seɪ jə hæv."

Marin al'Vere jumped, one hand clutching her throat, and stared. She looked years older than Nynaeve remembered. Worn. "Nynaeve? Nynaeve! Oh, it is you. Egwene? Have you brought Egwene back? Say you have."

"aɪ. . . ." nɪneɪiv pʊɾ ə hæn tə hɝ hɛd. wɛɹ ɪz ɛɡwin? ɪt simd ʃi ʃəd bi eɪbəl tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ. "noʊ. noʊ, aɪ hævən bɹɔɾ əɹ bæk." ðə weɪ bæk wɪl kʌm bʌt wʌns.

"I. . . ." Nynaeve put a hand to her head. Where is Egwene? It seemed she should be able to remember. "No. No, I haven't brought her back." The way back will come but once.

mɪstʃɹəs ælvɪɹ sæɡd ɪndə wʌn ə ðə stʃɹeɪt-bæk tʃɛɹz. "aɪ wɑz soʊ hoʊpɪŋ. ɛvɝ sɪns bɹæn daɪd. . . ."

Mistress al'Vere sagged into one of the straight-backed chairs. "I was so hoping. Ever since Bran died. . . ."

"bɹæn ɪz dɛd?" nɪneɪiv kəd nɑɾ ɪmædʒən ɪt; ðət bɹɔd, smaɪlɪŋ mæn hæɾ ɔlweɪz simd əz ɪf i wəd ɡoʊ ɑn fɝɛvɝ. "aɪ ʃʊɾə bɪn hɪɹ."

"Bran is dead?" Nynaeve could not imagine it; that broad, smiling man had always seemed as if he would go on forever. "I should have been here."

ði ʌðɝ wʊmən dʒʌmp tə hɝ fiɾ ən hɝid tə pɪɹ æŋkʃəsli θɹu ə wɪndoʊ ət ðə ɡɹin ən ðə vɪlədʒ. "ɪf mælɪnə noʊz jəɹ hɪɹ, ðəɹ wɪl bi tʃɹʌbəl. aɪ dʒʌs noʊ sɛn wɛn skɝiɪŋ ɔf tə faɪn hɝ. hiz ðə meɪɝ, naʊ."

The other woman jumped to her feet and hurried to peer anxiously through a window at the Green and the village. "If Malena knows you're here, there will be trouble. I just know Cenn went scurrying off to find her. He's the Mayor, now."

"sɛn? haʊ dɪɾ ivən ðoʊz wʊl-hɛɾəd mɛn tʃuz sɛn?"

"Cenn? How did even those wool-headed men choose Cenn?"

"ɪt wɑz mælɪnə. ʃi hæd ðə hoʊl wɪmənz sɝkəl æftɝ ðɛɹ hʌzbənz fəɹ hɪm." mɛɹɪn pɹɛst əɹ feɪs ɔlmoʊst əɡɛns ðə wɪndoʊ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lʊk ɛvɹi weɪ ət wʌns. "sɪli mɛn doʊn tɔk əbaʊt huz neɪm ðəɹ pʊɾɪŋ ɪn ðə bɑks bɪfɔɹhænd; aɪ səpoʊz ɛvɹi mæn u voʊɾəd fəɹ sɛn θɔɾ i wɑz ði oʊnli wʌn huz waɪf hæd bædʒɝɾ ɪm ɪndə ɪt. θɔt wʌn voʊt wəd meɪk noʊ dɪfɝəns. wɛl, ðeɪ lɝn bɛɾɝ. wi ɔl dɪd."

"It was Malena. She had the whole Women's Circle after their husbands for him." Marin pressed her face almost against the window, trying to look every way at once. "Silly men don't talk about whose name they're putting in the box beforehand; I suppose every man who voted for Cenn thought he was the only one whose wife had badgered him into it. Thought one vote would make no difference. Well, they learned better. We all did."

"hu ɪz ðɪs mælɪnə hu hæz ðə wɪmənz sɝkəl duɪŋ əɹ bɪɾɪŋ? aɪv nɛvɝ hɝɾ ə hɝ."

"Who is this Malena who has the Women's Circle doing her bidding? I've never heard of her."

"ʃiz fɹəm wɑtʃ hɪl. ʃiz ðə wɪs. . . ." mɛɹɪn tɝn fɹəm ðə wɪndoʊ ɹɪŋɪŋ əɹ hænz. "mælɪnə eɪlɝz ðə wɪzdəm, nɪneɪiv. wən jə dɪdn kʌm bæk. . . . laɪt, aɪ hoʊp ʃi dʌzn faɪn aʊt jəɹ hɪɹ."

"She's from Watch Hill. She's the Wis. . . ." Marin turned from the window wringing her hands. "Malena Aylar's the Wisdom, Nynaeve. When you didn't come back. . . . Light, I hope she doesn't find out you're here."

nɪneɪiv ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ ɪn wʌndɝ. "mɛɹɪn, jəɹ əfɹeɪɾ ə hɝ. jə ɑɹ ʃeɪkɪŋ. wʌt kaɪndə wʊmən ɪz ʃi? waɪ dɪd ðə wɪmənz sɝkəl ɛvɝ tʃuz sʌmwʌn laɪk hɝ?"

Nynaeve shook her head in wonder. "Marin, you're afraid of her. You are shaking. What kind of woman is she? Why did the Women's Circle ever choose someone like her?"

mɪstʃɹəs ælvɪɹ ɡeɪv ə bɪɾɝ læf. "wi mʌst əv bɪn mæd. mælɪnə keɪm daʊn tə si mævɹə mɔlən ðə deɪ bɪfɔɹ mævɹə hæd tə ɡoʊ bæk tə dɛvən ɹaɪd, ən ðət naɪt səm tʃɪlʒɹən tʊk sɪk, ən mælɪnə steɪd tə lʊk æftɝ ðɛm, ən ðən ðə ʃip stɑɹɾəd daɪɪŋ, ən mælɪnə tʊk kɛɹ ə ðæt, tu. ɪt dʒʌst sim nætʃɹəl tə tʃuz hɝ, bʌt. . . . ʃiz ə bʊli, nɪneɪiv. ʃi bɹaʊbits jə ɪndə duɪŋ wʌt ʃi wɑns. ʃi kips ət ju, ən kips ət ju, əntɪl jəɹ tu taɪɝd tə seɪ noʊ ɛnimɔɹ. ən wɝs. ʃi nɑkt ælsbɛt luhən daʊn."

Mistress al'Vere gave a bitter laugh. "We must have been mad. Malena came down to see Mavra Mallen the day before Mavra had to go back to Deven Ride, and that night some children took sick, and Malena stayed to look after them, and then the sheep started dying, and Malena took care of that, too. It just seemed natural to choose her, but. . . . She's a bully, Nynaeve. She browbeats you into doing what she wants. She keeps at you, and keeps at you, until you're too tired to say no anymore. And worse. She knocked Alsbet Luhhan down."

ə pɪktʃɝ flæʃt ɪn nɪneɪivz hɛɾ ʌv ælsbɛt luhən ən əɹ hʌzbənd, hɹəl, ðə blæksmɪθ. ʃi wɑz nɪɹli əz tɔl əz hɪm, ən staʊtli bɪlt, ðoʊ hænsəm. "ælsbɛts ɔlmoʊst əz stʃɹɔŋ əz hɹəl. aɪ kæn bɪliv. . . ."

A picture flashed in Nynaeve's head of Alsbet Luhhan and her husband, Haral, the blacksmith. She was nearly as tall as him, and stoutly built, though handsome. "Alsbet's almost as strong as Haral. I can't believe. . . ."

"mælɪnəz nɑɾ ə bɪɡ wʊmən, bʌt ʃiz - ʃiz fɪɹs, nɪneɪiv. ʃi biɾ ælsbɛɾ ɔl ɝaʊn ðə ɡɹin wɪð ə stɪk, ən nʌn ʌv əs u sɔ hæd ðə nɝv tə tʃɹaɪ tə stɑp ɪt. wən ðeɪ faʊn aʊt, bɹæn ən hɹəl sɛd ʃi hæd tə ɡoʊ, ivən ɪf ðeɪ wɝ ɪntɝfɪɹɪŋ ɪn wɪmənz sɝkəl bɪznəs. aɪ θɪŋk səm ə ðə sɝkəl maɪɾ əv lɪsənd, bʌt bɹæn ən hɹəl boʊθ tʊk sɪk ðə seɪm naɪt, ən daɪd wɪðɪn ə deɪ ʌv itʃ ʌðɝ." mɛɹɪn bɪɾ əɹ lɪp ən lʊkt ɝaʊn ðə ɹum əz ɪf ʃi θɔt sʌmwʌn maɪt bi haɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ. hɝ vɔɪs loʊɝd. "mælɪnə mɪks mɛɾəsən fəɹ ðɛm. ʃi sɛɾ ɪt wɑz əɹ duɾi ivən ɪf ðeɪ hæd spoʊkən əɡɛns hɝ. aɪ sɔ. . . . aɪ sɔ ɡɹeɪ fɛnəl ɪn wʌt ʃi tʊk əweɪ wɪð hɝ."

"Malena's not a big woman, but she's - she's fierce, Nynaeve. She beat Alsbet all around the Green with a stick, and none of us who saw had the nerve to try to stop it. When they found out, Bran and Haral said she had to go, even if they were interfering in Women's Circle business. I think some of the Circle might have listened, but Bran and Haral both took sick the same night, and died within a day of each other." Marin bit her lip and looked around the room as if she thought someone might be hiding there. Her voice lowered. "Malena mixed medicine for them. She said it was her duty even if they had spoken against her. I saw. . . . I saw gray fennel in what she took away with her."

nɪneɪiv ɡæspt. "bʌt. . . . ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ, mɛɹɪn? ɑɹ jə sɝɾən?" ði ʌðɝ wʊmən nɑɾəd, hɝ feɪs ɹɪŋkəlɪŋ ɑn ðə pɔɪn ə tɪɹz. "mɛɹɪn, ɪf jə ivən səspɛktəd ðɪs wʊmən maɪɾ əv pɔɪzən bɹæn, haʊ kəd jə nɑt ɡoʊ tə ðə sɝkəl?"

Nynaeve gasped. "But. . . . Are you sure, Marin? Are you certain?" The other woman nodded, her face wrinkling on the point of tears. "Marin, if you even suspected this woman might have poisoned Bran, how could you not go to the Circle?"

"ʃi sɛd bɹæn ən hɹəl dɪdnt wɔk ɪn ðə laɪt," mɛɹɪn mʌmbəld, "tɔkɪŋ əɡɛns ðə wɪzdəm ðə weɪ ðeɪ dɪd. ʃi sɛd ðət wɑz waɪ ðeɪ daɪd; ðə laɪɾ əbændən ðɛm. ʃi tɔks əbaʊt sɪn ɔl ðə taɪm. ʃi sɛd pəɾ ɑlkɑɹ sɪnd, tɔkɪŋ əɡɛnst əɹ æftɝ bɹæn ən hɹəl daɪd. ɔl i sɛd wɑz ʃi dɪdn əv ðə weɪ wɪð hilɪŋ jə dɪd, bʌt ʃi dʒɹu ðə dʒɹæɡənz fæŋ ɑn ɪz dɔɹ, ɹaɪɾ aʊt wɛɹ ɛvɹiwʌn kəd si hɝ wɪð ðə tʃɑɹkoʊl ɪn əɹ hænd. boʊθ ɪz bɔɪz wɝ dɛd bɪfɔɹ ðə wik wɑz aʊt - dʒʌs dɛd wən ðɛɹ mʌðɝ wɛn tə weɪk ðɛm. pʊɹ nɛlə. wi faʊn əɹ wɑndɝɪŋ, læfɪŋ ən kɹaɪɪŋ ɔl ət ðə seɪm taɪm, skɹimɪŋ ðət pət wɑz ðə dɑɹk wʌn, ən hid kɪld əɹ bɔɪz. pət hʌŋ hɪmsɛlf ðə nɛks deɪ." ʃi ʃʌɾɝəd, ən əɹ vɔɪs wɛn soʊ sɑf nɪneɪiv kəd bɛɹli hɪɹ ɪt. "aɪ hæv fɔɹ dɔɾɝz stɪl lɪvɪŋ ʌndɝ maɪ ɹuf. lɪvɪŋ, nɪneɪiv. dʒju ʌndɝstænd wʌɾ aɪm seɪɪŋ. ðəɹ stɪl əlaɪv, ən aɪ wɑnə kip əm əlaɪv."

"She said Bran and Haral didn't walk in the Light," Marin mumbled, "talking against the Wisdom the way they did. She said that was why they died; the Light abandoned them. She talks about sin all the time. She said Paet al'Caar sinned, talking against her after Bran and Haral died. All he said was she didn't have the way with Healing you did, but she drew the Dragon's Fang on his door, right out where everyone could see her with the charcoal in her hand. Both his boys were dead before the week was out - just dead when their mother went to wake them. Poor Nela. We found her wandering, laughing and crying all at the same time, screaming that Paet was the Dark One, and he'd killed her boys. Paet hung himself the next day." She shuddered, and her voice went so soft Nynaeve could barely hear it. "I have four daughters still living under my roof. Living, Nynaeve. Do you understand what I'm saying. They're still alive, and I want to keep them alive."

nɪneɪiv fɛl koʊl tə hɝ boʊnz. "mɛɹɪn, jə kæn əlaʊ ðɪs." ðə weɪ bæk wɪl kʌm bʌt wʌns. bi stɛdfæst. ʃi pʊʃt ɪɾ əweɪ. "ɪf ðə wɪmənz sɝkəl stænz təɡɛðɝ, jə kən bi ɹɪɾ ə hɝ."

Nynaeve felt cold to her bones. "Marin, you can't allow this." The way back will come but once. Be steadfast. She pushed it away. "If the Women's Circle stands together, you can be rid of her."

"stæn təɡɛðɝ əɡɛns mælɪnə?" mɛɹɪnz læf wɑz nɪɹɝ ə sɑb. "wɝ ɔl əfɹeɪɾ ə hɝ. bʌt ʃiz ɡʊd wɪð ðə tʃɪlʒɹən. ðəɹ ɑɹ ɔlweɪz tʃɪlʒɹən sɪk ðiz deɪz, ɪt simz, bʌt mælɪnə dʌz ðə bɛst ʃi kæn. ɔlmoʊs noʊ wʌn ɛvɝ daɪɾ ə sɪknəs wən jə wɝ wɪzdəm."

"Stand together against Malena?" Marin's laugh was nearer a sob. "We're all afraid of her. But she's good with the children. There are always children sick these days, it seems, but Malena does the best she can. Almost no one ever died of sickness when you were Wisdom."

"mɛɹɪn, lɪsən tə mi. doʊn jə si waɪ ðəɹ ɑɹ ɔlweɪz tʃɪlʒɹən sɪk? ɪf ʃi kæn meɪk jə əfɹeɪɾ ə hɝ, ʃi meɪks jə θɪŋk jə niɾ əɹ fəɹ ðə tʃɪlʒɹən. ʃiz duɪŋ ɪt, mɛɹɪn. dʒʌst əz ʃi dɪɾ ɪt tə bɹæn."

"Marin, listen to me. Don't you see why there are always children sick? If she can't make you afraid of her, she makes you think you need her for the children. She's doing it, Marin. Just as she did it to Bran."

"ʃi kʊdnt," mɛɹɪn bɹiðd. "ʃi wʊdnt. nɑt ðə lɪɾəl wʌnz."

"She couldn't," Marin breathed. "She wouldn't. Not the little ones."

"ʃi ɪz, mɛɹɪn." ðə weɪ bæk - nɪneɪiv səpɹɛs ðə θɔt ɹuθləsli. "ɪz ðəɹ ɛniwʌn ɪn ðə sɝkəl u ɪzən əfɹeɪd? ɛniwʌn u wɪl lɪsən?"

"She is, Marin." The way back - Nynaeve suppressed the thought ruthlessly. "Is there anyone in the Circle who isn't afraid? Anyone who will listen?"

ði ʌðɝ wʊmən sɛd, "noʊ wʌn u ɪzən əfɹeɪd. bʌt kɔɹɪn aɪɛlɪn maɪt lɪsən. ɪf ʃi dʌz, ʃi maɪt bɹɪŋ tu əɹ θɹi mɔɹ. nɪneɪiv, ɪf ɪnʌf ə ðə sɝkəl lɪsənz, wɪl jə bi əɹ wɪzdəm əɡɛn? aɪ θɪŋk jə meɪ bi ði oʊnli wʌn u woʊn bæk daʊn tə mælɪnə, ivən ɪf wi ɔl noʊ. jə doʊnt noʊ wʌt ʃiz laɪk."

The other woman said, "No one who isn't afraid. But Corin Ayellin might listen. If she does, she might bring two or three more. Nynaeve, if enough of the Circle listens, will you be our Wisdom again? I think you may be the only one who won't back down to Malena, even if we all know. You don't know what she's like."

"aɪ wɪl." ðə weɪ bæk - noʊ! ðiz ɑɹ maɪ pipəl! "ɡɛt jəɹ kloʊk, ən wɪl ɡoʊ tə kɔɹɪn."

"I will." The way back - No! These are my people! "Get your cloak, and we'll go to Corin."

mɛɹɪn wɑz hɛzɪɾənt əbaʊt livɪŋ ði ɪn, ən wʌns nɪneɪiv hæɾ əɹ aʊtsaɪd ʃi slʌŋk əlɔŋ fɹəm dɔɹstɛp tə dɔɹstɛp, kɹaʊtʃɪŋ ən wɑtʃɪŋ.

Marin was hesitant about leaving the inn, and once Nynaeve had her outside she slunk along from doorstep to doorstep, crouching and watching.

bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ wɝ hæfweɪ tə kɔɹɪn aɪɛlɪnz haʊs, nɪneɪiv sɔ ə tɔl, skɹɔni wʊmən stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ daʊn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə ɡɹin təwɔɹd ði ɪn, slæʃɪŋ ðə hɛdz ɔf widz wɪð ə θɪk wɪloʊ swɪtʃ. boʊni əz ʃi wɑz, ʃi hæɾ ə lʊk ʌv wɪɹi stʃɹɛŋkθ, ən ə sɛt, dɪtɝmən slæʃ ʌv ə maʊθ. sɛn bui skʌɾəld əlɔŋ ɪn əɹ weɪk.

Before they were halfway to Corin Ayellin's house, Nynaeve saw a tall, scrawny woman striding down the other side of the Green toward the inn, slashing the heads off weeds with a thick willow switch. Bony as she was, she had a look of wiry strength, and a set, determined slash of a mouth. Cenn Buie scuttled along in her wake.

"mælɪnə." mɛɹɪn pʊl nɪneɪiv ɪndə ðə speɪs bɪtwin tu haʊsəz, ən wɪspɝɾ əz ɪf əfɹeɪd ðə wʊmən maɪt hɪɹ əkɹɔs ðə ɡɹin. "aɪ nu sɛn wəd ɡoʊ tə hɝ."

"Malena." Marin pulled Nynaeve into the space between two houses, and whispered as if afraid the woman might hear across the Green. "I knew Cenn would go to her."

sʌmθɪŋ meɪd nɪneɪiv lʊk oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. bɪhaɪn əɹ stʊɾ ə sɪlvɝ ɑɹtʃ, ɹitʃɪŋ fɹəm haʊs tə haʊs, ɡloʊɪŋ waɪtli. ðə weɪ bæk wɪl kʌm bʌt wʌns. bi stɛdfæst.

Something made Nynaeve look over her shoulder. Behind her stood a silver arch, reaching from house to house, glowing whitely. The way back will come but once. Be steadfast.

mɛɹɪn ɡeɪv ə sɑf skɹim. "ʃiz sin ʌs. laɪt hɛlp ʌs, ʃiz kʌmɪŋ ðɪs weɪ!"

Marin gave a soft scream. "She's seen us. Light help us, she's coming this way!"

ðə tɔl wʊmən hæd tɝn əkɹɔs ðə ɡɹin, livɪŋ sɛn stændɪŋ ənsɝteɪnli. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ənsɝɾənti ɑn mælɪnəz feɪs. ʃi wɔk sloʊli, əz ɪf ðəɹ wɝ noʊ hoʊp ʌv ɪskeɪp, ə kɹuəl smaɪl ɡɹoʊɪŋ wɪð ɛvɹi stɛp.

The tall woman had turned across the Green, leaving Cenn standing uncertainly. There was no uncertainty on Malena's face. She walked slowly, as if there were no hope of escape, a cruel smile growing with every step.

mɛɹɪn tʌɡd ət nɪneɪivz sliv. "wi hæv tə ɹʌn. wɪv tə haɪd. nɪneɪiv, kʌm ɑn. sɛn wɪl əv toʊld əɹ u jə ɑɹ. ʃi heɪts ɛniwʌn ivən tə spik ə ju."

Marin tugged at Nynaeve's sleeve. "We have to run. We have to hide. Nynaeve, come on. Cenn will have told her who you are. She hates anyone even to speak of you."

ðə sɪlvɝ ɑɹtʃ pʊl nɪneɪivz aɪz. ðə weɪ bæk. . . . ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ. ɪts nɑt ɹil. ʃi lʊkt ət mɛɹɪn; stɑɹk tɛɹɝ twɪstəd ðə wʊmənz feɪs. jə mʌs bi stɛdfæs tə sɝvaɪv.

The silver arch pulled Nynaeve's eyes. The way back. . . . She shook her head, trying to remember. It is not real. She looked at Marin; stark terror twisted the woman's face. You must be steadfast to survive.

"pliz, nɪneɪiv. ʃiz sin mi wɪð ju. ʃi - hæz - sin - mi! pliz, nɪneɪiv!"

"Please, Nynaeve. She's seen me with you. She - has - seen - me! Please, Nynaeve!"

mælɪnə keɪm kloʊsɝ, ɪmplækəbəl. maɪ pipəl. ði ɑɹtʃ ʃoʊn. ðə weɪ bæk. ɪts nɑt ɹil.

Malena came closer, implacable. My people. The arch shone. The way back. It is not real.

wɪð ə sɑb, nɪneɪiv tɔɹ əɹ ɑɹm aʊɾ ə mɛɹɪnz ɡɹæsp ən plʌnʒd təwɔɹd ðə sɪlvɝi ɡloʊ.

With a sob, Nynaeve tore her arm out of Marin's grasp and plunged toward the silvery glow.

mɛɹɪnz ʃɹik haʊndɪd hɝ. "fɔɹ ðə lʌv ə ðə laɪt, nɪneɪiv, hɛlp mi! hɛlp meɪn!"

Marin's shriek hounded her. "For the love of the Light, Nynaeve, help me! HELP ME!"

ðə ɡloʊ ɛnvɛləp hɝ.

The glow enveloped her.

* * * stɛɹɪŋ, nɪneɪiv stæɡɝɾ aʊɾ ə ði ɑɹtʃ, bɛɹli əwɛɹ ə ðə tʃeɪmbɝ əɹ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. mɛɹɪnz læs kɹaɪ stɪl ɹæŋ ɪn əɹ ɪɹz. ʃi dɪd nɑt flɪntʃ wən koʊld wɔɾɝ wɑz sʌɾənli pɔɹɾ oʊvɝ əɹ hɛd.

* * * Staring, Nynaeve staggered out of the arch, barely aware of the chamber or the Aes Sedai. Marin's last cry still rang in her ears. She did not flinch when cold water was suddenly poured over her head.

"ju ɑɹ wɑʃt klin ə fɔls pɹaɪd. jə ɑɹ wɑʃt klin ə fɔls æmbɪʃən. jə kʌm tə əs wɑʃt klin, ɪn hɑɹɾ ən soʊl." əz ðə ɹɛɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ stɛp bæk, ʃɛɹiəm keɪm tə teɪk nɪneɪivz ɑɹm.

"You are washed clean of false pride. You are washed clean of false ambition. You come to us washed clean, in heart and soul." As the Red Aes Sedai stepped back, Sheriam came to take Nynaeve's arm.

nɪneɪiv ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt, ðən ɹilaɪzd u ɪt wɑz. ʃi siz ðə kɑlɝ ə ʃɛɹiəmz dʒɹɛs ɪn boʊθ hænz. "tɛl mi ɪt wɑz nɑt ɹil. tɛl mi!"

Nynaeve gave a start, then realized who it was. She seized the collar of Sheriam's dress in both hands. "Tell me it was not real. Tell me!"

"bæd?" ʃɛɹiəm pɹaɪɾ əɹ hænz lus əz ɪf ʃi wɝ juz tə ðɪs ɹiækʃən. "ɪɾ ɪz ɔlweɪz wɝs, ən ðə θɝɾ ɪz ðə wɝst ʌv ɔl."

"Bad?" Sheriam pried her hands loose as if she were used to this reaction. "It is always worse, and the third is the worst of all."

"aɪ lɛf maɪ fɹɛnd . . . aɪ lɛf maɪ pipəl . . . ɪn ðə pɪɾ ə dum tə kʌm bæk." pliz, laɪt, ɪt wɑz nɑt ɹil. aɪ dɪdn ɹɪli. . . . aɪ hæv tə meɪk mɔɪɹeɪn peɪ. aɪ hæv tə!

"I left my friend . . . I left my people . . . in the Pit of Doom to come back." Please, Light, it was not real. I didn't really. . . . I have to make Moiraine pay. I have to!

"ðɛɹ ɪz ɔlweɪz səm ɹizən nɑt tə ɹɪtɝn, sʌmθɪŋ tə pɹɪvɛn ju, əɹ dɪstʃɹæk ju. ðɪs tɛɹæŋɡɹil wivz tʃɹæps fəɹ jə fɹəm jəɹ oʊn maɪnd, wivz əm taɪɾ ən stʃɹɔŋ, hɑɹɾɝ ðən stil ən mɔɹ dɛdli ðən pɔɪzən. ðəɾ ɪz waɪ wi juz ɪɾ əz ə tɛst. jə mʌst wɑnə bi ɛɛs sədaɪ mɔɹ ðən ɛniθɪŋ ɛls ɪn ðə hoʊl wɝld, ɪnʌf tə feɪs ɛniθɪŋ, faɪt fɹi ʌv ɛniθɪŋ, tə ətʃiv ɪt. ðə waɪt taʊɝ kænɑɾ æksɛp lɛs. wi dɪmæn ɪɾ ə ju."

"There is always some reason not to return, something to prevent you, or distract you. This ter'angreal weaves traps for you from your own mind, weaves them tight and strong, harder than steel and more deadly than poison. That is why we use it as a test. You must want to be Aes Sedai more than anything else in the whole world, enough to face anything, fight free of anything, to achieve it. The White Tower cannot accept less. We demand it of you."

"ju dɪmæn ə ɡɹeɪt dil." nɪneɪiv stɛɹɾ ət ðə θɝɾ ɑɹtʃ əz ðə ɹɛd-hɛɹɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ tʊk əɹ təwɔɹɾ ɪt. ðə θɝɾ ɪz ðə wɝst. "aɪm əfɹeɪd," ʃi wɪspɝd. wʌt kəd bi wɝs ðən wʌɾ aɪ dʒʌs dɪd?

"You demand a great deal." Nynaeve stared at the third arch as the red-haired Aes Sedai took her toward it. The third is the worst. "I'm afraid," she whispered. What could be worse than what I just did?

"ɡʊd," ʃɛɹiəm sɛd. "ju sik tə bi ɛɛs sədaɪ, tə tʃænəl ðə wʌn paʊɝ. noʊ wʌn ʃəɾ əpɹoʊtʃ ðət wɪθaʊt fɪɹ ən ɑ. fɪɹ wɪl kip jə kɔʃəs; kɑʃən wɪl kip jə əlaɪv." ʃi tɝnd nɪneɪiv tə feɪs ði ɑɹtʃ, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt stɛp bæk ɪmiɾiətli. "noʊ wʌn wɪl fɔɹs jə tə ɛntɝ ə θɝd taɪm, tʃaɪld."

"Good," Sheriam said. "You seek to be Aes Sedai, to channel the One Power. No one should approach that without fear and awe. Fear will keep you cautious; caution will keep you alive." She turned Nynaeve to face the arch, but she did not step back immediately. "No one will force you to enter a third time, child."

nɪneɪiv lɪkt əɹ lɪps. "ɪf aɪ ɹɛfjus, jəl pʊt mi aʊɾ ə ðə taʊɝ ən nɛvɝ lemi kʌm bæk." ʃɛɹiəm nɑɾəd. "æn ðɪs ɪz ðə wɝst." ʃɛɹiəm nɑɾəd əɡɛn. nɪneɪiv dʒɹu bɹɛθ. "aɪ æm ɹɛɾi."

Nynaeve licked her lips. "If I refuse, you'll put me out of the Tower and never let me come back." Sheriam nodded. "And this is the worst." Sheriam nodded again. Nynaeve drew breath. "I am ready."

"ðə θɝd taɪm," ʃɛɹiəm ɪntoʊn fɔɹməli, "ɪz fəɹ wʌt wɪl bi. ðə weɪ bæk wɪl kʌm bʌt wʌns. bi stɛdfæst."

"The third time," Sheriam intoned formally, "is for what will be. The way back will come but once. Be steadfast."

nɪneɪiv θɹu hɝsɛlf ət ði ɑɹtʃ ɪn ə ɹʌn.

Nynaeve threw herself at the arch in a run.

læfɪŋ, ʃi ɹæn θɹu swɝlɪŋ klaʊdz ə bʌɾɝflaɪz ɹaɪzɪŋ fɹəm waɪld-flaʊɝz ðət kʌvɝd ðə hɪltɑp mɛdoʊ wɪð ə ni-dip blæŋkəɾ ə kʌlɝ. hɝ ɡɹeɪ mɛɹ dæns nɝvəsli, ɹeɪnz dæŋɡəlɪŋ, ət ði ɛdʒ ə ðə mɛdoʊ, ən nɪneɪiv stɑpt ɹʌnɪŋ soʊ əz nɑt tə fɹaɪɾən ði ænəməl mɔɹ. səm ə ðə bʌɾɝflaɪz sɛɾəld ɑn əɹ dʒɹɛs, ɑn flaʊɝz ʌv ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi ən sid pɝlz, əɹ flɪɾɝd ɝaʊn ðə sæfaɪɝz ən munstoʊnz ɪn əɹ hɛɹ, hæŋɪŋ lus əbaʊɾ əɹ ʃoʊldɝz.

Laughing, she ran through swirling clouds of butterflies rising from wild-flowers that covered the hilltop meadow with a knee-deep blanket of color. Her gray mare danced nervously, reins dangling, at the edge of the meadow, and Nynaeve stopped running so as not to frighten the animal more. Some of the butterflies settled on her dress, on flowers of embroidery and seed pearls, or flittered around the sapphires and moonstones in her hair, hanging loose about her shoulders.

bɪloʊ ðə hɪl, ðə nɛkləs ə ðə θaʊzən leɪks spɹɛd θɹu ðə sɪɾi ʌv mɔlkiɝ, ɹəflɛktɪŋ ðə klaʊd-bɹʌʃɪŋ sɛvən taʊɝz, wɪð ɡoʊldən kɹeɪn bænɝz flaɪɪŋ ət ðɛɹ haɪts ɪn ðə mɪsts. ðə sɪɾi hæɾ ə θaʊzənd ɡɑɹɾənz, bʌt ʃi pɹəfɝd ðɪs waɪld ɡɑɹɾən ɑn ðə hɪltɑp. ðə weɪ bæk wɪl kʌm bʌt wʌns. bi stɛdfæst.

Below the hill, the necklace of the Thousand Lakes spread through the city of Malkier, reflecting the cloud-brushing Seven Towers, with Golden Crane banners flying at their heights in the mists. The city had a thousand gardens, but she preferred this wild garden on the hilltop. The way back will come but once. Be steadfast.

ðə saʊn ə hʊvz meɪɾ əɹ tɝn.

The sound of hooves made her turn.

ælən mænʒɹɑɡɔɹən, kɪŋ ə mɔlkiɝ, lɛp fɹəm ðə bæk ə hɪz tʃɑɹdʒɝ ən stʃɹoʊl təwɔɹɾ əɹ θɹu ðə bʌɾɝflaɪz, læfɪŋ. hɪz feɪs hæd ðə lʊk ʌv ə hɑɹd mæn, bʌt ðə smaɪlz i wɔɹ fəɹ əɹ sɔfən ðə stoʊni pleɪnz.

Al'Lan Mandragoran, King of Malkier, leaped from the back of his charger and strolled toward her through the butterflies, laughing. His face had the look of a hard man, but the smiles he wore for her softened the stony planes.

ʃi ɡeɪpt ət hɪm, teɪkən baɪ sɝpɹaɪz wən i ɡæðɝɾ əɹ ɪndə hɪz ɑɹmz ən kɪs hɝ. fəɹ ə moʊmənt ʃi klʌŋ tə hɪm, lɔst, kɪsɪŋ ɪm bæk. hɝ fit dæŋɡəld ə fʊɾ ɪn ði ɛɹ, ən ʃi dɪd nɑt kɛɹ.

She gaped at him, taken by surprise when he gathered her into his arms and kissed her. For a moment she clung to him, lost, kissing him back. Her feet dangled a foot in the air, and she did not care.

sʌɾənli ʃi pʊʃt ət hɪm, pʊld əɹ feɪs bæk. "noʊ." ʃi pʊʃt hɑɹɾɝ. "lɛt mi ɡoʊ. pʊt mi daʊn." pʌzəld, hi loʊɝɾ əɹ əntɪl əɹ fit tʌtʃt ɡɹaʊnd; ʃi bækt əweɪ fɹəm hɪm. "nɑt ðɪs," ʃi sɛd. "aɪ kænɑt feɪs ðɪs. ɛniθɪŋ bʌt ðɪs." pliz, lemi feɪs eɪdʒɪnɝ əɡɛn. mɛmɹi swɝld. eɪdʒɪnɝ? ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ wɛɹ ðət θɔt hæd kʌm fɹʌm. mɛmɹi lɝtʃt ən tɪltəd, ʃɪftɪŋ fɹæɡməns laɪk bɹoʊkən aɪs ɑn ə flʌɾɪŋ ɹɪvɝ. ʃi klɔd fəɹ ðə pisəz, klɔd fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ tə hæŋ ɑn tə.

Suddenly she pushed at him, pulled her face back. "No." She pushed harder. "Let me go. Put me down." Puzzled, he lowered her until her feet touched ground; she backed away from him. "Not this," she said. "I cannot face this. Anything but this." Please, let me face Aginor again. Memory swirled. Aginor? She did not know where that thought had come from. Memory lurched and tilted, shifting fragments like broken ice on a flooding river. She clawed for the pieces, clawed for something to hang on to.

"ɑɹ jə wɛl, maɪ lʌv?" læn æskt wɝidli.

"Are you well, my love?" Lan asked worriedly.

"du nɑt kɔl mi ðæt! aɪm nɑt jəɹ lʌv! aɪ kænɑt mɛɹi ju!"

"Do not call me that! I am not your love! I cannot marry you!"

hi stɑɹɾəld əɹ baɪ θɹoʊɪŋ bæk ɪz hɛɾ ən ɹɔɹɪŋ wɪð læftɝ. "jɔɹ ɪmpləkeɪʃən ðət wəɹ nɑt mɛɹid maɪɾ əpsɛɾ əɹ tʃɪlʒɹən, waɪf. ən haʊ ɑɹ jə nɑt maɪ lʌv? aɪ hæv noʊ ʌðɝ, ən wɪl əv noʊ ʌðɝ."

He startled her by throwing back his head and roaring with laughter. "Your implication that we are not married might upset our children, wife. And how are you not my love? I have no other, and will have no other."

"aɪ mʌst ɡoʊ bæk." dɛspɝətli ʃi lʊk fəɹ ði ɑɹtʃ, faʊn oʊnli mɛdoʊ ən skaɪ. hɑɹɾɝ ðən stil ən mɔɹ dɛdli ðən pɔɪzən. læn. lænz beɪbiz. laɪt, hɛlp mi! "aɪ mʌst ɡoʊ bæk naʊ."

"I must go back." Desperately she looked for the arch, found only meadow and sky. Harder than steel and more deadly than poison. Lan. Lan's babies. Light, help me! "I must go back now."

"ɡoʊ bæk? wɛɹ? tə ɛmənz fild? ɪf jə wɪʃ ɪt. əl sɛn lɛɾɝz tə mɔɹɡeɪs, ən kəmæn ən ɛskɔɹt."

"tæŋɡəld ʌp ɪn wʌt, nɪneɪiv? wʌɾ ɪz ɪt jə kʊdn bɛɹ? noʊ, nɪneɪiv. jə kən ɹaɪɾ əloʊn hɪɹ ɪf jə wɪʃ ɪt, bʌɾ ɪf ðə kwin ə ðə mɔlkɪɹi keɪm tə ændɝ wɪθaʊɾ ə pɹɑpɝ ɛskɔɹt, mɔɹɡeɪs wəd bi skændəlaɪzd, ɪf nɑɾ əfɛndəd. jə doʊnt wɑnə əfɛn hɝ, də ju? aɪ θɔt jə tu wɝ fɹɛnz."

"Tangled up in what, Nynaeve? What is it you couldn't bear? No, Nynaeve. You can ride alone here if you wish it, but if the Queen of the Malkieri came to Andor without a proper escort, Morgase would be scandalized, if not offended. You don't want to offend her, do you? I thought you two were friends."

nɪneɪiv fɛlt əz ɪf ʃi hæd bɪn hɪɾ ɪn ðə hɛd, bloʊ æftɝ deɪzɪŋ bloʊ. "kwin?" ʃi sɛd hɛzɪɾəntli. "wi hæv beɪbiz?"

Nynaeve felt as if she had been hit in the head, blow after dazing blow. "Queen?" she said hesitantly. "We have babies?"

"ɑɹ jə sɝɾən jəɹ wɛl? aɪ θɪŋk aɪ hæd bɛɾɝ teɪk jə tə ʃɛɝinə sədaɪ."

"Are you certain you're well? I think I had better take you to Sharina Sedai."

"noʊ." ʃi bækt əweɪ fɹəm ɪm əɡɛn. "noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ." ɪɾ ɪzən ɹil. aɪ woʊn bi pʊld ɪndə ɪt ðɪs taɪm. aɪ woʊnt!

"No." She backed away from him again. "No Aes Sedai." It isn't real. I won't be pulled into it this time. I won't!

"vɛɹi wɛl," hi sɛd sloʊli. "æz maɪ waɪf, haʊ kəd jə nɑt bi kwin? wəɹ mɔlkɪɹi hɪɹ, nɑt saʊθlændɝz. jə wɝ kɹaʊn ɪn ðə sɛvən taʊɝz ət ðə seɪm taɪm wi ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ɹɪŋz." ʌnkɑnʃəsli hi muvd ɪz lɛf hænd; ə pleɪn ɡoʊl bæn ɪnsɝkəld ɪz fɔɹfɪŋɡɝ. ʃi ɡlænst əɾ əɹ oʊn hænd, ət ðə ɹɪŋ ʃi nu wəd bi ðɛɹ; ʃi klæspt əɹ ʌðɝ hæn oʊvɝ ɪt, bʌt wɛðɝ tə dɪnaɪ ɪts pɹɛzəns baɪ haɪɾɪŋ ɪɾ əɹ tə hoʊld ɪt, ʃi kəd nɑɾ əv sɛd. "æz jə wɪʃ, maɪ lʌv. wɪv θɹi tʃɪlʒɹən, ðoʊ oʊnli wʌn kən pɹɑpɝli bi kɔld ə beɪbi. mæɹɪk ɪz ɔlmoʊs tə jəɹ ʃoʊldɝ ən kæn dɪsaɪɾ ɪf i laɪks hɔɹsəz əɹ bʊks bɛɾɝ. ɪlnɔɹ əz ɔlɹɛɾi bɪɡʌn pɹæktəsɪŋ haʊ tə tɝn bɔɪz' hɛdz, wən ʃiz nɑt pɛstɝɪŋ ʃɛɝinə əbaʊt wən ʃɪl bi oʊld ɪnʌf tə ɡoʊ tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ."

"Very well," he said slowly. "As my wife, how could you not be Queen? We are Malkieri here, not southlanders. You were crowned in the Seven Towers at the same time we exchanged rings." Unconsciously he moved his left hand; a plain gold band encircled his forefinger. She glanced at her own hand, at the ring she knew would be there; she clasped her other hand over it, but whether to deny its presence by hiding it or to hold it, she could not have said. "Do you remember, now?" he went on. He stretched out a hand as if to brush her cheek, and she went back another six steps. He sighed. "As you wish, my love. We have three children, though only one can properly be called a baby. Maric is almost to your shoulder and can't decide if he likes horses or books better. Elnore has already begun practicing how to turn boys' heads, when she is not pestering Sharina about when she'll be old enough to go to the White Tower."

"ɪlnɔɹ wɑz maɪ mʌðɝz neɪm," ʃi sɛd sɔfli.

"Elnore was my mother's name," she said softly.

"soʊ jə sɛd wən jə tʃoʊz ɪt. nɪneɪiv - "

"So you said when you chose it. Nynaeve - "

"noʊ. əl nɑt bi pʊld ɪndə ɪt ðɪs taɪm. nɑt ðɪs. aɪ woʊnt!" bɪɑn hɪm, əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz bɪsaɪd ðə mɛdoʊ, ʃi sɔ ðə sɪlvɝ ɑɹtʃ. ðə tʃɹiz hæd hɪɾən ɪt bɪfɔɹ. ðə weɪ bæk wɪl kʌm bʌt wʌns. ʃi tɝn təwɔɹɾ ɪt. "aɪ mʌst ɡoʊ." hi kɑɾ əɹ hænd, ən ɪt wɑz əz ɪf əɹ fit hæd bɪkʌm ɹuɾəd ɪn stoʊn; ʃi kəd nɑt meɪk hɝsɛlf pʊl əweɪ.

The way back will come but once. She turned toward it. "I must go." He caught her hand, and it was as if her feet had become rooted in stone; she could not make herself pull away.

"aɪ də nɑt noʊ wʌɾ ɪz tʃɹʌbəlɪŋ ju, waɪf, bʌt wʌtɛvɝ ɪɾ ɪz, tɛl mi ən əl meɪk ɪt ɹaɪt. aɪ noʊ aɪm nɑt ðə bɛst ə hʌzbənz. aɪ wɑz ɔl hɑɹɾ ɛdʒəz wən aɪ faʊn ju, bʌt juv smuð səm ə ðɛm əweɪ, ət list."

"aɪ kænɑt." ði ɑɹtʃ stʊd ðɛɹ, oʊnli ə fju stɛps əweɪ. ðə weɪ bæk wɪl kʌm bʌt wʌns. bi stɛdfæst.

"You are the very best of husbands," she murmured. To her horror, she found herself remembering him as her husband, remembering laughter and tears, bitter arguments and sweet making up. They were dim memories, but she could feel them growing stronger, warmer. "I cannot." The arch stood there, only a few steps away. The way back will come but once. Be steadfast.

"aɪ də nɑt noʊ wʌɾ ɪz hæpənɪŋ, nɪneɪiv, bʌɾ aɪ fil əz ɪf aɪ wɝ luzɪŋ ju. aɪ kəd nɑt bɛɹ ðæt." hi pʊɾ ə hæn ɪn əɹ hɛɹ; kloʊzɪŋ əɹ aɪz, ʃi pɹɛst əɹ tʃik əɡɛnst ɪz fɪŋɡɝz. "steɪ wɪð mi, ɔlweɪz."

læn tɝn əɹ tə feɪs hɪm. "wʌt tʃɹʌbəlz ju? jə mʌs tɛl mi ɪf aɪm tə hɛlp."

"ðɪs ɪz nɑt ɹil."

"Not real? Before I met you, I thought nothing except the sword was real. Look around you, Nynaeve. It is real. Whatever you want to be real, we can make real together, you and I."

wʌndɝɪŋli, ʃi dɪd lʊk ɝaʊnd. ðə mɛdoʊ wɑz stɪl ðɛɹ. ðə sɛvən taʊɝz stɪl stʊɾ oʊvɝ ðə θaʊzən leɪks. ði ɑɹtʃ wɑz ɡɔn, bʌt nʌθɪŋ ɛls hæd tʃeɪnʒd. aɪ kəd steɪ hɪɹ. wɪð læn. nʌθɪŋ əz tʃeɪnʒd. hɝ θɔts tɝnd. nʌθɪŋ əz tʃeɪnʒd. ɛɡwin ɪz əloʊn ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ɹænd wɪl tʃænəl ðə paʊɝ ən ɡoʊ mæd. ən wʌɾ ə mæt ən pɛɹɪn? kən ðeɪ teɪk bæk ɛni ʃɹɛɾ ə ðɛɹ laɪvz? ən mɔɪɹeɪn, hu tɔɹ ɔl əɹ lɪvz əpɑɹt, stɪl wɔks fɹi.

Wonderingly, she did look around. The meadow was still there. The Seven Towers still stood over the Thousand Lakes. The arch was gone, but nothing else had changed. I could stay here. With Lan. Nothing has changed. Her thoughts turned. Nothing has changed. Egwene is alone in the White Tower. Rand will channel the Power and go mad. And what of Mat and Perrin? Can they take back any shred of their lives? And Moiraine, who tore all our lives apart, still walks free.

"aɪ mʌst ɡoʊ bæk," ʃi wɪspɝd. əneɪbəl tə bɛɹ ðə peɪn ɑn ɪz feɪs, ʃi pʊl fɹi ʌv hɪm. dɪlɪbɝətli ʃi fɔɹmd ə flaʊɝ bʌɾ ɪn əɹ maɪnd, ə waɪt bʌɾ ɑn ə blækθɝn bɹæntʃ. ʃi meɪd ðə θɔɹnz ʃɑɹp ən kɹuəl, wɪʃɪŋ ðeɪ kəd pɪɹs əɹ flɛʃ, filɪŋ əz ɪf ʃi ɔlɹɛɾi hʌŋ ɪn ðə blækθɝnz bɹæntʃəz. ʃɛɹiəm sədaɪz vɔɪs dæns dʒʌst aʊɾ ə hɪɹɪŋ, tɛlɪŋ əɹ ɪt wɑz deɪnʒɝəs tə ətɛmp tə tʃænəl ðə paʊɝ. ðə bʌɾ oʊpənd, ən seɪaɪdɑɹ fɪld əɹ wɪð laɪt.

"I must go back," she whispered. Unable to bear the pain on his face, she pulled free of him. Deliberately she formed a flower bud in her mind, a white bud on a blackthorn branch. She made the thorns sharp and cruel, wishing they could pierce her flesh, feeling as if she already hung in the blackthorn's branches. Sheriam Sedai's voice danced just out of hearing, telling her it was dangerous to attempt to channel the Power. The bud opened, and saidar filled her with light.

"nɪneɪiv, tɛl mi wʌɾ ɪz ðə mæɾɝ."

"Nynaeve, tell me what is the matter."

lænz vɔɪs slɪɾ əkɹɔs əɹ kɑnsəntʃɹeɪʃən; ʃi ɹəfjuz tə lɛt hɝsɛlf hɪɹ ɪt. ðəɹ hæd tə bi ə weɪ bæk stɪl. stɛɹɪŋ ət wɛɹ ðə sɪlvɝ ɑɹtʃ hæd bɪn, ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə faɪn səm tʃɹeɪs ʌv ɪt. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ.

Lan's voice slid across her concentration; she refused to let herself hear it. There had to be a way back still. Staring at where the silver arch had been, she tried to find some trace of it. There was nothing.

"nɪneɪiv . . ."

"Nynaeve . . ."

ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə pɪktʃɝ ði ɑɹtʃ ɪn əɹ maɪnd, tə ʃeɪp ɪɾ ən fɔɹm ɪt tə ðə læs dɪteɪl, kɝv ʌv ɡlimɪŋ mɛɾəl fɪld wɪð ə ɡloʊ laɪk snoʊi faɪɝ. ɪt sim tə weɪvɝ ðɛɹ, ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ, fɝs ðəɹ bɪtwin əɹ ən ðə tʃɹiz, ðən nɑt, ðən ðɛɹ.

She tried to picture the arch in her mind, to shape it and form it to the last detail, curve of gleaming metal filled with a glow like snowy fire. It seemed to waver there, in front of her, first there between her and the trees, then not, then there.

". . . aɪ lʌv jə . . ."

". . . I love you . . ."

ʃi dʒɹu ət seɪaɪdɑɹ, dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ ɪn ðə floʊ ʌv ðə wʌn paʊɝ tɪl ʃi θɔt ʃi wəd bɝst. ðə ɹeɪdʒjəns fɪlɪŋ hɝ, ʃaɪnɪŋ ɝaʊn hɝ, hɝɾ əɹ oʊn aɪz. ðə hit sim tə kənsum hɝ. ðə flɪkɝɪŋ ɑɹtʃ fɝmd, stɛɾid, stʊd hoʊl bɪfɔɹ hɝ. faɪɝ ən peɪn sim tə fɪl hɝ; hɝ boʊnz fɛlt əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ bɝnɪŋ; hɝ skʌl simd ə ɹɔɹɪŋ fɝnəs.

She drew at saidar, drinking in the flow of the One Power till she thought she would burst. The radiance filling her, shining around her, hurt her own eyes. The heat seemed to consume her. The flickering arch firmed, steadied, stood whole before her. Fire and pain seemed to fill her; her bones felt as if they were burning; her skull seemed a roaring furnace.

". . . wɪð ɔl maɪ hɑɹt."

". . . with all my heart."

ʃi ɹæn təwɔɹd ðə sɪlvɝ kɝv, nɑt lɛɾɪŋ hɝsɛlf lʊk bæk. ʃi hæd bɪn ʃʊɹ ðə bɪɾɝəst θɪŋ ʃi wəɾ ɛvɝ hɪɹ wɑz mɛɹɪn ælvɪɹz kɹaɪ fəɹ hɛlp əz nɪneɪiv əbændən hɝ, bʌt ðət wɑz hʌni bɪsaɪd ðə saʊn ə lænz æŋɡwɪʃt vɔɪs pɝsuɪŋ hɝ. "nɪneɪiv, pliz doʊn liv mi."

She ran toward the silver curve, not letting herself look back. She had been sure the bitterest thing she would ever hear was Marin al'Vere's cry for help as Nynaeve abandoned her, but that was honey beside the sound of Lan's anguished voice pursuing her. "Nynaeve, please don't leave me."

ðə waɪt ɡloʊ kənsum hɝ.

The white glow consumed her.

neɪkəd, nɪneɪiv stæɡɝd θɹu ði ɑɹtʃ ən fɛl tə hɝ niz, slæk-maʊðd ən sɑbɪŋ, tɪɹz stʃɹimɪŋ daʊn əɹ tʃiks. ʃɛɹiəm nɛl bɪsaɪd hɝ. ʃi ɡlɛɹɾ ət ðə ɹɛd-hɛɹɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ. "aɪ heɪt ju!" ʃi mænədʒ fɪɹsli, ɡʌlpɪŋ. "aɪ heɪɾ ɔl ɛɛs sədaɪ!"

Naked, Nynaeve staggered through the arch and fell to her knees, slack-mouthed and sobbing, tears streaming down her cheeks. Sheriam knelt beside her. She glared at the red-haired Aes Sedai. "I hate you!" she managed fiercely, gulping. "I hate all Aes Sedai!"

ʃɛɹiəm ɡeɪv ə smɔl saɪ, ðən pʊl nɪneɪiv tə hɝ fit. "tʃaɪld, ɔlmoʊst ɛvɹi wʊmən u dʌz ðɪs sɛz mʌtʃ ðə seɪm θɪŋ. ɪts noʊ smɔl θɪŋ tə bi meɪd tə feɪs jəɹ fɪɹz. wʌɾ ɪz ðɪs?" ʃi sɛd ʃɑɹpli, tɝnɪŋ nɪneɪivz pɑmz ʌp.

Sheriam gave a small sigh, then pulled Nynaeve to her feet. "Child, almost every woman who does this says much the same thing. It is no small thing to be made to face your fears. What is this?" she said sharply, turning Nynaeve's palms up.

nɪneɪivz hænz kwɪvɝd wɪð ə sʌɾən peɪn ʃi hæd nɑt fɛl bɪfɔɹ. dʒɹɪvən θɹu ðə pɑm ʌv itʃ hænd, ɹaɪɾ ɪn ðə sɛntɝ, wɑz ə lɔŋ blæk θɔɹn. ʃɛɹiəm dʒɹu ðɛm aʊt kɛɹfəli; nɪneɪiv fɛl ðə kul hilɪŋ ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪz tʌtʃ. wən itʃ θɔɹn keɪm fɹi, ɪt lɛft oʊnli ə smɔl skɑɹ ɑn fɹʌn ən bæk ə ðə hænd.

Nynaeve's hands quivered with a sudden pain she had not felt before. Driven through the palm of each hand, right in the center, was a long black thorn. Sheriam drew them out carefully; Nynaeve felt the cool Healing of the Aes Sedai's touch. When each thorn came free, it left only a small scar on front and back of the hand.

ʃɛɹiəm fɹaʊnd. "ðɛɹ ʃʊdn bi ɛni skɑɹɪŋ. ən haʊ dɪd jə oʊnli ɡɛt tu, ən boʊθ pleɪst soʊ pɹɪsaɪsli? ɪf jə tæŋɡəl jɝsɛlf ɪn ə blækθɝn bʊʃ, jə ʃəd bi kʌvɝd wɪð skɹætʃəz ən θɔɹnz."

Sheriam frowned. "There shouldn't be any scarring. And how did you only get two, and both placed so precisely? If you tangled yourself in a blackthorn bush, you should be covered with scratches and thorns."

"aɪ ʃʊd," nɪneɪiv əɡɹid bɪɾɝli. "meɪbi aɪ θɔɾ aɪ hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi peɪɾ ɪnʌf."

"I should," Nynaeve agreed bitterly. "Maybe I thought I had already paid enough."

"ðɛɹ ɪz ɔlweɪz ə pɹaɪs," ði ɛɛs sədaɪ əɡɹid. "kʌm, naʊ. juv peɪd ðə fɝs pɹaɪs. teɪk wʌt juv peɪd fɔɹ." ʃi ɡeɪv nɪneɪiv ə slaɪt pʊʃ fɔɹwɝd.

"There is always a price," the Aes Sedai agreed. "Come, now. You have paid the first price. Take what you have paid for." She gave Nynaeve a slight push forward.

nɪneɪiv ɹilaɪz ðəɹ wɝ mɔɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ðə tʃeɪmbɝ. ði æmɪɝlɪn ɪn əɹ stʃɹaɪp stoʊl wɑz ðɛɹ, wɪð ə ʃɔl sɪstɝ fɹəm itʃ ədʒɑ ɹeɪnʒd tə iðɝ saɪɾ ə hɝ, ɔl ə ðɛm wɑtʃɪŋ nɪneɪiv. ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ʃɛɹiəmz ɪnstʃɹʌkʃən, nɪneɪiv tɑɾɝd fɔɹwɝɾ ən nɛl bɪfɔɹ ði æmɪɝlɪn. ɪt wɑz ʃi hu hɛl ðə læs tʃælɪs, ən ʃi tɪpt ɪt sloʊli oʊvɝ nɪneɪivz hɛd.

Nynaeve realized there were more Aes Sedai in the chamber. The Amyrlin in her striped stole was there, with a shawled sister from each Ajah ranged to either side of her, all of them watching Nynaeve. Remembering Sheriam's instruction, Nynaeve tottered forward and knelt before the Amyrlin. It was she who held the last chalice, and she tipped it slowly over Nynaeve's head.

"ju ɑɹ wɑʃt klin ə nɪneɪiv ælmɛɹə fɹəm ɛmənz fild. jə ɑɹ wɑʃt klin ʌv ɔl taɪz ðət baɪn jə tə ðə wɝld. jə kʌm tə əs wɑʃt klin, ɪn hɑɹɾ ən soʊl. jə ɑɹ nɪneɪiv ælmɛɹə, æksɛptɪɾ ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ." hændɪŋ ðə tʃælɪs tə wʌn ə ðə sɪstɝz, ði æmɪɝlɪn dʒɹu nɪneɪiv tə hɝ fit. "ju ɑɹ sil tə ʌs, naʊ."

"You are washed clean of Nynaeve al'Maera from Emond's Field. You are washed clean of all ties that bind you to the world. You come to us washed clean, in heart and soul. You are Nynaeve al'Maera, Accepted of the White Tower." Handing the chalice to one of the sisters, the Amyrlin drew Nynaeve to her feet. "You are sealed to us, now."

ði æmɪɝlɪnz aɪz sim tə hoʊld ə dɑɹk ɡloʊ. nɪneɪivz ʃɪvɝ hæd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð biɪŋ neɪkəɾ ən wɛt.

The Amyrlin's eyes seemed to hold a dark glow. Nynaeve's shiver had nothing to do with being naked and wet.


tʃæptɝ twɛntifɔɹ


CHAPTER 24

nu fɹɛnz ən oʊld ɛnəmiz


New Friends and Old Enemies

ɛɡwin fɑloʊd ði æksɛptɪd θɹu ðə hɔlz ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ. tæpəstʃɹiz ən peɪntɪŋz kʌvɝd wɔlz əz waɪɾ əz ði aʊtsaɪɾ ə ðə taʊɝ; pæɾɝnd taɪlz meɪd ðə flɔɹ. ði æksɛptɪdz waɪt dʒɹɛs wɑz ɪɡzækli laɪk hɝz, ɪksɛp fəɹ sɛvən nɛɹoʊ bænz ə kʌlɝ ət hɛm ən kʌfs. ɛɡwin fɹaʊnd, lʊkɪŋ ət ðət dʒɹɛs. sɪns jɛstɝdeɪ nɪneɪiv hæd wɔɹn ən æksɛptɪdz dʒɹɛs, ən ʃi sim tə hæv noʊ dʒɔɪ ʌv ɪt, nɔɹ ə ðə ɡoʊldən ɹɪŋ, ə sɝpən iɾɪŋ ɪts oʊn teɪl, ðət mɑɹkt əɹ lɛvəl. ðə fju taɪmz ɛɡwin hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə si ðə wɪzdəm, nɪneɪivz aɪz hæd simd ʃæɾoʊd, əz ɪf ʃi hæd sin θɪŋz ʃi wɪʃt wɪð ɔl əɹ hɑɹt nɑt tə hæv sin.

Egwene followed the Accepted through the halls of the White Tower. Tapestries and paintings covered walls as white as the outside of the tower; patterned tiles made the floor. The Accepted's white dress was exactly like hers, except for seven narrow bands of color at hem and cuffs. Egwene frowned, looking at that dress. Since yesterday Nynaeve had worn an Accepted's dress, and she seemed to have no joy of it, nor of the golden ring, a serpent eating its own tail, that marked her level. The few times Egwene had been able to see the Wisdom, Nynaeve's eyes had seemed shadowed, as if she had seen things she wished with all her heart not to have seen.

"ɪn hɪɹ," ði æksɛptɪd sɛd kɝtli, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ tə ə dɔɹ. neɪm peɪdʒɹə, ʃi wɑz ə ʃɔɹt, wɪɹi wʊmən, ə lɪɾəl oʊldɝ ðən nɪneɪiv, ən wɪð ə bɹɪsknəs ɔlweɪz ɪn əɹ vɔɪs. "jɔɹ ɡɪvən ðɪs taɪm kəz ɪts jəɹ fɝs deɪ, bʌɾ əl ɪkspɛk jə ɪn ðə skʌlɝi wən ðə ɡɔŋ saʊnz haɪ, ən nɑt wʌn moʊmən leɪɾɝ."

"In here," the Accepted said curtly, gesturing to a door. Named Pedra, she was a short, wiry woman, a little older than Nynaeve, and with a briskness always in her voice. "You're given this time because it is your first day, but I'll expect you in the scullery when the gong sounds High, and not one moment later."

ɛɡwin kɝtsid, ðən stʌk aʊɾ əɹ tʌŋ ət ði æksɛptɪdz ɹitʃɹiɾɪŋ bæk. ɪt maɪɾ əv bɪn oʊnli ði ivnɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ðət ʃɛɹiəm hæd faɪnəli pʊɾ əɹ neɪm ɪn ðə nɑvəs bʊk, bʌɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ʃi nu ʃi dɪd nɑt laɪk peɪdʒɹə. ʃi pʊʃt oʊpən ðə dɔɹ ən wɛn ɪn.

Egwene curtsied, then stuck out her tongue at the Accepted's retreating back. It might have been only the evening before that Sheriam had finally put her name in the novice book, but already she knew she did not like Pedra. She pushed open the door and went in.

ðə ɹum wɑz pleɪn ən smɔl, wɪð waɪt wɔlz, ən ðəɹ wɑz ə jʌŋ wʊmən, wɪð ɹɛɾɪʃ ɡoʊl hɛɹ spɪlɪŋ ɝaʊn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz, sɪɾɪŋ ɑn wʌn ə tu hɑɹd bɛntʃɪz. ðə flɔɹ wɑz bɛɹ; nɑvəsɪz dɪd nɑt ɡɛt mʌtʃ jus ə ɹumz wɪð kɑɹpəts. ɛɡwin θɔt ðə ɡɝl wɑz əbaʊɾ əɹ oʊn eɪdʒ, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ə dɪɡnəɾi ən sɛlf-pəzɛʃən əbaʊɾ əɹ ðət meɪɾ əɹ sim oʊldɝ. ðə pleɪnli kʌt nɑvəs dʒɹɛs əpɪɹd sʌmhaʊ mɔɹ, ɑn hɝ. ɛləɡənt. ðət wɑz ɪt.

The room was plain and small, with white walls, and there was a young woman, with reddish gold hair spilling around her shoulders, sitting on one of two hard benches. The floor was bare; novices did not get much use of rooms with carpets. Egwene thought the girl was about her own age, but there was a dignity and self-possession about her that made her seem older. The plainly cut novice dress appeared somehow more, on her. Elegant. That was it.

"maɪ neɪm ɪz ɪleɪn," ʃi sɛd. ʃi tɪltəɾ əɹ hɛd, stʌɾiɪŋ ɛɡwin. "æn jə ɑɹ ɛɡwin. fɹəm ɛmənz fild, ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz." ʃi sɛɾ ɪɾ əz ɪf ɪt hæd səm səɡnɪfɪkəns, bʌt wɛn ɹaɪɾ ɑn ɛniweɪ. "sʌmwʌn u hæz bɪn hɪɹ ə lɪɾəl waɪl ɪz ɔlweɪz əsaɪn tə ə nu nɑvəs fəɹ ə fju deɪz, tə hɛlp əɹ faɪn əɹ weɪ. sɪt, pliz."

"My name is Elayne," she said. She tilted her head, studying Egwene. "And you are Egwene. From Emond's Field, in the Two Rivers." She said it as if it had some significance, but went right on anyway. "Someone who has been here a little while is always assigned to a new novice for a few days, to help her find her way. Sit, please."

ɛɡwin tʊk ði ʌðɝ bɛntʃ, feɪsɪŋ ɪleɪn. "aɪ θɔt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wəd titʃ mi, naʊ ðəɾ aɪm faɪnəli ə nɑvəs. bʌɾ ɔl ðæts hæpən soʊ fɑɹ ɪz ðət peɪdʒɹə woʊk mi ə ɡʊd tu aʊɝz bɪfɔɹ fɝs laɪɾ ən pʊt mi tə swipɪŋ ðə hɔlz. ʃi sɛz aɪ hæv tə hɛlp wɑʃ dɪʃəz æftɝ dɪnɝ, tu."

Egwene took the other bench, facing Elayne. "I thought the Aes Sedai would teach me, now that I'm finally a novice. But all that's happened so far is that Pedra woke me a good two hours before first light and put me to sweeping the halls. She says I have to help wash dishes after dinner, too."

ɪleɪn ɡɹɪməst. "aɪ heɪt wɑʃɪŋ dɪʃəz. aɪ nɛvɝ hæd tə - wɛl, ðət dʌzn mæɾɝ. jəl əv tʃɹeɪnɪŋ. fɹəm naʊ ɑn, jəl bi ət tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ət ðɪs aʊɝ ɛvɹi deɪ, əz ə mæɾɝ ə fækt. fɹəm bɹɛkfəst əntɪl haɪ, ðən əɡɛn fɹəm dɪnɝ tə tʃɹaɪn. ɪf jə ɑɹ ɪspɛʃli kwɪk əɹ ɪspɛʃli sloʊ, ðeɪ meɪ teɪk jə fɹəm sʌpɝ tə fʊl, əz wɛl, bʌt ðəɾ ɪz juʒəwəli fəɹ mɔɹ tʃɔɹz." ɪleɪnz blu aɪz tʊk ɑn ə θɔtfəl ɪkspɹɛʃən. "ju wɝ bɔɹn wɪð ɪt, wɝn ju?" ɛɡwin nɑɾəd. "jɛs, aɪ θɔɾ aɪ fɛlt ɪt. soʊ wɑz aɪ, bɔɹn wɪð ɪt. də nɑt bi dɪsəpɔɪntɪɾ ɪf jə dɪd nɑt noʊ. jəl lɝn tə fil ði əbɪləɾi ɪn ʌðɝ wɪmən. aɪ hæd ði ædvæntɪdʒ ʌv ɡɹoʊɪŋ ʌp ɝaʊn ən ɛɛs sədaɪ."

Elayne grimaced. "I hate washing dishes. I never had to - well, that doesn't matter. You will have training. From now on, you will be at training at this hour every day, as a matter of fact. From breakfast until High, then again from dinner to Trine. If you are especially quick or especially slow, they may take you from supper to Full, as well, but that is usually for more chores." Elayne's blue eyes took on a thoughtful expression. "You were born with it, weren't you?" Egwene nodded. "Yes, I thought I felt it. So was I, born with it. Do not be disappointed if you did not know. You will learn to feel the ability in other women. I had the advantage of growing up around an Aes Sedai."

ɛɡwin wɑntəd tə æsk əbaʊt ðət - hu ɡɹoʊz ʌp wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ? - bʌɾ ɪleɪn wɛn ɑn.

Egwene wanted to ask about that - Who grows up with Aes Sedai? - but Elayne went on.

"æn ɔlsoʊ də nɑt bi dɪsəpɔɪntɪɾ ɪf ɪt teɪks jə səm taɪm bɪfɔɹ jə kən ətʃiv ɛniθɪŋ. wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ, aɪ min. ivən ðə sɪmpləs θɪŋ teɪks ə lɪɾəl taɪm. peɪʃəns ɪz ə vɝtʃu ðət mʌs bi lɝnd." hɝ noʊz ɹɪŋkəld. "ʃɛɹiəm sədaɪ ɔlweɪz sɛz ðæt, ən ʃi dʌz əɹ bɛs tə meɪk əs ɔl lɝn ɪt, tu. tʃɹaɪ tə ɹʌn wən ʃi sɛz wɔk, ən ʃɪl əv jə ɪn əɹ stʌɾi bɪfɔɹ jə kən blɪŋk."

"And also do not be disappointed if it takes you some time before you can achieve anything. With the One Power, I mean. Even the simplest thing takes a little time. Patience is a virtue that must be learned." Her nose wrinkled. "Sheriam Sedai always says that, and she does her best to make us all learn it, too. Try to run when she says walk, and she'll have you in her study before you can blink."

"aɪv hæɾ ə fju lɛsənz ɔlɹɛɾi," ɛɡwin sɛd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə saʊn mɑɾəst. ʃi oʊpən hɝsɛlf tə seɪaɪdɑɹ - ðət pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt wɑz iziɝ naʊ - ən fɛl ðə wɔɹmθ sʌfjus əɹ bɑɾi. ʃi dɪsaɪɾɪd tə tʃɹaɪ ðə bɪɡəs θɪŋ ʃi nu haʊ tə du. ʃi stʃɹɛtʃt aʊɾ əɹ hænd, ən ə ɡloʊɪŋ sfɪɹ fɔɹmd oʊvɝ ɪt, pjʊɹ laɪt. ɪt weɪvɝd - ʃi stɪl kəd nɑt mænədʒ tə hoʊld ɪt stɛɾi - bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðɛɹ.

"I've had a few lessons already," Egwene said, trying to sound modest. She opened herself to saidar - that part of it was easier now - and felt the warmth suffuse her body. She decided to try the biggest thing she knew how to do. She stretched out her hand, and a glowing sphere formed over it, pure light. It wavered - she still could not manage to hold it steady - but it was there.

kɑmli, ɪleɪn hɛld aʊɾ əɹ hænd, ən ə bɔl ə laɪɾ əpɪɹɾ əbʌv əɹ pɑm. hɝz flɪkɝd, tu.

Calmly, Elayne held out her hand, and a ball of light appeared above her palm. Hers flickered, too.

æftɝ ə moʊmənt, ə feɪn laɪt ɡloʊɾ ɔl ɝaʊn ɪleɪn. ɛɡwin ɡæspt, ən əɹ bɔl vænɪʃt.

After a moment, a faint light glowed all around Elayne. Egwene gasped, and her ball vanished.

ɪleɪn ɡɪɡəl sʌɾənli, ən əɹ laɪt wɛn aʊt, boʊθ ðə sfɪɹ ən ðə laɪɾ ɝaʊn hɝ. "ju sɔ ɪɾ ɝaʊn mi?" ʃi sɛɾ ɪksaɪɾədli. "aɪ sɔ ɪɾ ɝaʊn ju. ʃɛɹiəm sədaɪ sɛɾ aɪ wʊd, ɪvɛntʃəwəli. ðɪs wɑz ðə fɝs taɪm. fəɹ ju, tu?"

Elayne giggled suddenly, and her light went out, both the sphere and the light around her. "You saw it around me?" she said excitedly. "I saw it around you. Sheriam Sedai said I would, eventually. This was the first time. For you, too?"

ɛɡwin nɑɾəd, læfɪŋ əlɔŋ wɪð ði ʌðɝ ɡɝl. "aɪ laɪk ju, ɪleɪn. aɪ θɪŋk wɝ gɑnə bi fɹɛnz."

Egwene nodded, laughing along with the other girl. "I like you, Elayne. I think we're going to be friends."

"aɪ θɪŋk soʊ, tu, ɛɡwin. jə ɑɹ fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, fɹəm ɛmənz fild. dʒju noʊ ə bɔɪ neɪmd ɹænd ælθɹ?"

"I think so, too, Egwene. You are from the Two Rivers, from Emond's Field. Do you know a boy named Rand al'Thor?"

"aɪ noʊ hɪm." əbɹʌpli ɛɡwin faʊn hɝsɛlf ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ə teɪl ɹænd hæd toʊld, ə teɪl ʃi hæd nɑt bɪlivd, əbaʊt fɔlɪŋ ɔf ə wɔl ɪndə ə ɡɑɹɾən ən miɾɪŋ. . . . "jɔɹ ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ʌv ændɝ," ʃi ɡæspt.

"I know him." Abruptly Egwene found herself remembering a tale Rand had told, a tale she had not believed, about falling off a wall into a garden and meeting. . . . "You're the Daughter-Heir of Andor," she gasped.

"jɛs," ɪleɪn sɛd sɪmpli. "ɪf ʃɛɹiəm sədaɪ əz mʌtʃ əz hɝɾ aɪd mɛnʃən ɪt, aɪ θɪŋk ʃi wəɾ əv mi ɪndə hɝ stʌɾi bɪfɔɹ aɪ fɪnɪʃt tɔkɪŋ."

"Yes," Elayne said simply. "If Sheriam Sedai as much as heard I'd mentioned it, I think she would have me into her study before I finished talking."

"ɛvɹiwʌn tɔks əbaʊt biɪŋ kɔl tə ʃɛɹiəmz stʌɾi. ivən ði æksɛptɪd. dʌz ʃi skoʊl soʊ fɪɹsli? ʃi simz kaɪnli tə mi."

"Everyone talks about being called to Sheriam's study. Even the Accepted. Does she scold so fiercely? She seems kindly to me."

ɪleɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ən wən ʃi spoʊk ɪt wɑz sloʊli, nɑt miɾɪŋ ɛɡwinz aɪ. "ʃi kips ə wɪloʊ swɪtʃ ɑn əɹ dɛsk. ʃi sɛz ɪf jə kæn lɝn tə fɑloʊ ðə ɹulz ɪn ə sɪvəlaɪzd weɪ, ʃɪl titʃ jə ənʌðɝ weɪ. ðəɹ ɑɹ soʊ mɛni ɹulz fəɹ nɑvəsɪz, ɪts vɛɹi hɑɹd nɑt tə bɹeɪk səm ə ðɛm," ʃi fɪnɪʃt.

Elayne hesitated, and when she spoke it was slowly, not meeting Egwene's eye. "She keeps a willow switch on her desk. She says if you can't learn to follow the rules in a civilized way, she will teach you another way. There are so many rules for novices, it is very hard not to break some of them," she finished.

"bʌt ðæts - ðæts hɔɹəbəl! aɪm nɑɾ ə tʃaɪld, ən niðɝ ɑɹ ju. aɪ woʊn bi tʃɹiɾəd əz wʌn."

"But that's - that's horrible! I'm not a child, and neither are you. I won't be treated as one."

"bʌt wəɹ tʃɪlʒɹən. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðə fʊl sɪstɝz, ɑɹ ðə ɡɹoʊn wɪmən. ði æksɛptɪɾ ɑɹ ðə jʌŋ wɪmən, oʊld ɪnʌf tə bi tʃɹʌstɪd wɪθaʊt sʌmwʌn lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz ɛvɹi moʊmənt. ən nɑvəsɪz ɑɹ ðə tʃɪlʒɹən, tə bi pɹətɛktəɾ ən kɛɹd fɔɹ, ɡaɪɾəd ɪn ðə weɪ ðeɪ ʃəd ɡoʊ, ən pʌnɪʃt wən ðeɪ də wʌt ðeɪ ʃəd nɑt. ðəɾ ɪz ðə weɪ ʃɛɹiəm sədaɪ ɪkspleɪnz ɪt. noʊ wʌn ɪz gɑnə pʌnɪʃ jə oʊvɝ jəɹ lɛsənz, nɑɾ ənlɛs jə tʃɹaɪ sʌmθɪŋ juv bɪn toʊl nɑt tə. ɪts hɑɹd nɑt tə tʃɹaɪ, səmtaɪmz; jəl faɪn jə wɑnə tʃænəl əz mʌtʃ əz jə wɑnə bɹið. bʌɾ ɪf jə bɹeɪk tu mɛni dɪʃəz kəz jə ɑɹ deɪdʒɹimɪŋ wən jə ʃəd bi wɑʃɪŋ, ɪf jəɹ dɪsɹɪspɛkfəl tə ən æksɛptɪd, əɹ liv ðə taʊɝ wɪθaʊt pɝmɪʃən, əɹ spik tə ən ɛɛs sədaɪ bɪfɔɹ ʃi spiks tə ju, ɔɹ. . . . ði oʊnli θɪŋ tə də ɪz ðə bɛs jə kæn. ðəɹ ɪzən ɛniθɪŋ ɛls tə du."

"But we are children. The Aes Sedai, the full sisters, are the grown women. The Accepted are the young women, old enough to be trusted without someone looking over their shoulders every moment. And novices are the children, to be protected and cared for, guided in the way they should go, and punished when they do what they should not. That is the way Sheriam Sedai explains it. No one is going to punish you over your lessons, not unless you try something you've been told not to. It is hard not to try, sometimes; you will find you want to channel as much as you want to breathe. But if you break too many dishes because you are daydreaming when you should be washing, if you're disrespectful to an Accepted, or leave the Tower without permission, or speak to an Aes Sedai before she speaks to you, or. . . . The only thing to do is the best you can. There isn't anything else to do."

"ɪt saʊnz ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf ðəɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk əs wɑnə liv," ɛɡwin pɹətɛstəd.

"It sounds almost as if they're trying to make us want to leave," Egwene protested.

"ðeɪ ɑɹənt, bʌt ðən əɡɛn, ðeɪ ɑɹ. ɛɡwin, ðəɹ ɑɹ oʊnli fɔɹɾi nɑvəsɪz ɪn ðə taʊɝ. oʊnli fɔɹɾi, ən noʊ mɔɹ ðən sɛvən əɹ eɪt wɪl bɪkʌm æksɛptɪd. ðəɾ ɪz nɑɾ ɪnʌf, ʃɛɹiəm sədaɪ sɛz. ʃi sɛz ðəɹ ɑɹ nɑɾ ɪnʌf ɛɛs sədaɪ naʊ tə də wʌt nidz tə bi dʌn. bʌt ðə taʊɝ wɪl nɑt . . . kænɑt . . . loʊɝ ɪts stændɝdz. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ kænɑt teɪk ə wʊmən əz ə sɪstɝ ɪf ʃi dʌz nɑɾ əv ði əbɪləɾi, ən ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ, ən ðə dɪzaɪɝ. ðeɪ kænt ɡɪv ðə ɹɪŋ ən ðə ʃɔl tə wʌn u kænɑt tʃænəl ðə paʊɝ wɛl ɪnʌf, əɹ u wɪl əlaʊ hɝsɛlf tə bi ɪntɪmɪdeɪɾɪd, əɹ u wɪl tɝn bæk wən ðə ɹoʊd tɝnz ɹʌf. tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ən tɛstɪŋ teɪk kɛɹ ə ðə tʃænəlɪŋ, ən fəɹ stʃɹɛŋkθ ən dɪzaɪɝ. . . . wɛl, ɪf jə wɑnə ɡoʊ, ðəl lɛt ju. wʌns jə noʊ ɪnʌf ðət jə woʊn daɪ ʌv ɪɡnɝəns."

"They aren't, but then again, they are. Egwene, there are only forty novices in the Tower. Only forty, and no more than seven or eight will become Accepted. That is not enough, Sheriam Sedai says. The Aes Sedai cannot take a woman as a sister if she does not have the ability, and the strength, and the desire. They can't give the ring and the shawl to one who cannot channel the Power well enough, or who will allow herself to be intimidated, or who will turn back when the road turns rough. Training and testing take care of the channeling, and for strength and desire. . . . Well, if you want to go, they will let you. Once you know enough that you won't die of ignorance."

"aɪ səpoʊz," ɛɡwin sɛd sloʊli, "ʃɛɹiəm toʊld əs səm ə ðæt. aɪ nɛvɝ θɔɾ əbaʊt ðəɹ nɑt biɪŋ ɪnʌf ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðoʊ."

"ʃi hæz ə θɪɹi. ʃi sɛz wɪv kʌl hjumənkaɪnd. jə noʊ əbaʊt kʌlɪŋ? kʌɾɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə hɝd ðoʊz ænəməlz ðəɾ əv tʃɹeɪts jə doʊn laɪk?" ɛɡwin nɑɾəd ɪmpeɪʃənli; noʊ wʌn kəd ɡɹoʊ ʌp ɝaʊnd ʃip wɪθaʊt noʊɪŋ əbaʊt kʌlɪŋ ðə flɑk. "ʃɛɹiəm sədaɪ sɛz ðət wɪð ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ hʌntɪŋ daʊn mɛn u kəd tʃænəl fəɹ θɹi θaʊzən jɪɹz, wəɹ kʌlɪŋ ði əbɪləɾi tə tʃænəl aʊɾ ʌv əs ɔl. aɪ wəd nɑt mɛnʃən ðɪs ɝaʊn ɛni ɹɛdz, ɪf aɪ wɝ ju. ʃɛɹiəm sədaɪ hæz bɪn ɪn mɔɹ ðən wʌn ʃaʊɾɪŋ mætʃ oʊvɝ ɪt, ən wəɹ oʊnli nɑvəsɪz."

"She has a theory. She says we have culled humankind. You know about culling? Cutting out of the herd those animals that have traits you don't like?" Egwene nodded impatiently; no one could grow up around sheep without knowing about culling the flock. "Sheriam Sedai says that with the Red Ajah hunting down men who could channel for three thousand years, we are culling the ability to channel out of us all. I would not mention this around any Reds, if I were you. Sheriam Sedai has been in more than one shouting match over it, and we are only novices."

"aɪ woʊnt."

"I won't."

ɪleɪn pɔzd, ən ðən sɛd, "ɪz ɹænd wɛl?"

Elayne paused, and then said, "Is Rand well?"

ɛɡwin fɛlt ə sʌɾən stæb ə dʒɛləsi - ɪleɪn wɑz vɛɹi pɹɪɾi - bʌɾ oʊvɝ ɪt keɪm ə stʃɹɔŋɝ stæb ə fɪɹ. ʃi wɛn oʊvɝ ðə lɪɾəl ʃi nu ʌv ɹændz wʌn miɾɪŋ wɪð ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ, ɹiəʃʊɹɪŋ hɝsɛlf: ɪleɪn kəd nɑt pɑsəbli noʊ ðət ɹænd kəd tʃænəl.

Egwene felt a sudden stab of jealousy - Elayne was very pretty - but over it came a stronger stab of fear. She went over the little she knew of Rand's one meeting with the Daughter-Heir, reassuring herself: Elayne could not possibly know that Rand could channel.

"ɛɡwin?"

"Egwene?"

"hi ɪz əz wɛl əz i kən bi." aɪ hoʊp i ɪz, ðə wʊl-hɛɾəd ɪɾiət. "hi wɑz ɹaɪɾɪŋ wɪð səm ʃaɪnɝən soʊlʒɝz ðə læst aɪ sɔ hɪm."

"He is as well as he can be." I hope he is, the wool-headed idiot. "He was riding with some Shienaran soldiers the last I saw him."

"ʃaɪnɝənz! hi toʊl mi hi wɑz ə ʃɛpɝd." ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "aɪ faɪn maɪsɛlf θɪŋkɪŋ ə hɪm ət ði ɑɾəst taɪmz. ɪleɪɾə θɪŋks hiz ɪmpɔɹɾənt ɪn səm weɪ. ʃi dɪdn kʌm ɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ən seɪ soʊ, bʌt ʃi ɔɹɾɝd ə sɝtʃ fəɹ hɪm, ən ʃi wɑz ɪn ə fjʊɹi wən ʃi lɝn i hæd lɛf keɪɛmlɪn."

"Shienarans! He told me he was a shepherd." She shook her head. "I find myself thinking of him at the oddest times. Elaida thinks he is important in some way. She didn't come right out and say so, but she ordered a search for him, and she was in a fury when she learned he had left Caemlyn."

"ɪleɪɾə?"

"Elaida?"

"ɪleɪɾə sədaɪ. maɪ mʌðɝz kaʊnsəlɝ. ʃiz ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ, bʌt mʌðɝ simz tə laɪk əɹ dɪspaɪt ðæt."

"Elaida Sedai. My mother's councilor. She is Red Ajah, but Mother seems to like her despite that."

ɛɡwinz maʊθ fɛl dʒɹaɪ. ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ, ən ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn ɹænd. "aɪ - aɪ doʊnt noʊ wɛɹ i ɪz, naʊ. hi lɛft ʃaɪnɝ, ən aɪ doʊn θɪŋk i wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ bæk."

Egwene's mouth felt dry. Red Ajah, and interested in Rand. "I - I don't know where he is, now. He left Shienar, and I don't think he was going back."

ɪleɪn ɡeɪv əɹ ə lɛvəl lʊk. "aɪ wəd nɑt tɛl ɪleɪɾə wɛɹ tə faɪn ɪm ɪf aɪ nu, ɛɡwin. hiz dʌn noʊ ɹɔŋ ðəɾ aɪ noʊ, ən aɪ fɪɹ ʃi wɑns tə juz ɪm ɪn səm mænɝ. ɛniweɪ, aɪv nɑt sin əɹ sɪns ðə deɪ wi ɝaɪvd, wɪð waɪtkloʊks dɔɡɪŋ əɹ tʃɹeɪl. ðeɪ ɑɹ stɪl kæmpt ɑn ðə dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊn saɪd." əbɹʌpli ʃi baʊndəd tə hɝ fit. "lɛɾ əs tɔk ə hæpiɝ θɪŋz. ðəɹ ɑɹ tu ʌðɝz hɪɹ u noʊ ɹænd, ən aɪ wəd laɪk jə tə mit wʌn ə ðɛm." ʃi tʊk ɛɡwinz hæn ən pʊld əɹ aʊɾ ə ðə ɹum.

Elayne gave her a level look. "I would not tell Elaida where to find him if I knew, Egwene. He has done no wrong that I know, and I fear she wants to use him in some manner. Anyway, I've not seen her since the day we arrived, with Whitecloaks dogging our trail. They are still camped on the Dragonmount side." Abruptly she bounded to her feet. "Let us talk of happier things. There are two others here who know Rand, and I would like you to meet one of them." She took Egwene's hand and pulled her out of the room.

"tu ɡɝlz? ɹænd simz tə miɾ ə lɑɾ ʌv ɡɝlz."

"Two girls? Rand seems to meet a lot of girls."

"m?" stɪl dʒɹɔɪŋ ɛɡwin daʊn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ, ɪleɪn stʌɾid hɝ. "jɛs. wɛl. wʌn ə ðɛm ɪz ə leɪzi tʃɪt neɪmd ɛls ɡɹɪnwɛl. aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ʃɪl bi hɪɹ lɔŋ. ʃi ʃɝks əɹ tʃɔɹz, ən ʃiz ɔlweɪz snikɪŋ ɔf tə wɑtʃ ðə wɔɹɾɝz pɹæktəs ðɛɹ sɔɹdz. ʃi sɛz ɹænd keɪm tə hɝ fɑðɝz fɑɹm, wɪð ə fɹɛn ə hɪz. mæt. ɪt simz ðeɪ pʊt noʊʃənz ə ðə wɝl bɪɑn ðə nɛks vɪlədʒ ɪndə hɝ hɛd, ən ʃi ɹæn əweɪ tə kʌm bi ən ɛɛs sədaɪ."

"Ummm?" Still drawing Egwene down the corridor, Elayne studied her. "Yes. Well. One of them is a lazy chit named Else Grinwell. I don't think she will be here long. She shirks her chores, and she is always sneaking off to watch the Warders practice their swords. She says Rand came to her father's farm, with a friend of his. Mat. It seems they put notions of the world beyond the next village into her head, and she ran away to come be an Aes Sedai."

"mɛn," ɛɡwin mʌɾɝd. "aɪ dæns ə fju dænsəz wɪð ə naɪs bɔɪ, ən ɹænd ɡoʊz ɝaʊn lʊkɪŋ laɪk ə dɔɡ wɪð ə sɔɹ tuθ, bʌɾ i - " ʃi kʌɾ ɔf əz ə mæn stɛpt ɪndə ðə hɔl əhɛɾ ə ðɛm. bɪsaɪd hɝ, ɪleɪn stɑpt, tu, ən əɹ hæn taɪɾənd ɑn ɛɡwinz.

"Men," Egwene muttered. "I dance a few dances with a nice boy, and Rand goes around looking like a dog with a sore tooth, but he - " She cut off as a man stepped into the hall ahead of them. Beside her, Elayne stopped, too, and her hand tightened on Egwene's.

ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ əlɑɹmɪŋ əbaʊt hɪm, əsaɪd fɹəm ðə sʌɾənnəs ə hɪz əpɪɹəns. hi wɑz tɔl ən hænsəm, ʃɔɹɾ ə mɪɾəl jɪɹz, wɪð lɔŋ, dɑɹk kɝlɪŋ hɛɹ, bʌɾ ɪz ʃoʊldɝz sæɡd, ən ðəɹ wɑz sædnəs ɪn ɪz aɪz. hi meɪd noʊ muv təwɔɹɾ ɛɡwin ən ɪleɪn, oʊnli stʊd lʊkɪŋ əɾ əm əntɪl wʌn ə ði æksɛptɪɾ əpɪɹɾ əɾ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ.

There was nothing alarming about him, aside from the suddenness of his appearance. He was tall and handsome, short of middle years, with long, dark curling hair, but his shoulders sagged, and there was sadness in his eyes. He made no move toward Egwene and Elayne, only stood looking at them until one of the Accepted appeared at his shoulder.

"ju ʃəd nɑt bi ɪn hɪɹ," ʃi sɛd tə hɪm, nɑɾ əŋkinli.

"You should not be in here," she said to him, not unkindly.

"aɪ wɑntəd tə wɔk." hɪz vɔɪs wɑz dip, ən əz sæɾ əz ɪz aɪz.

"I wanted to walk." His voice was deep, and as sad as his eyes.

"ju kən wɔk aʊɾ ɪn ðə ɡɑɹɾən, wɛɹ jə ɑɹ səpoʊz tə bi. ðə sʌnʃaɪn wɪl bi ɡʊd fəɹ ju."

"You can walk out in the garden, where you are supposed to be. The sunshine will be good for you."

ðə mæn ɹʌmbəld ə bɪɾɝ læf. "wɪð tu əɹ θɹi ʌv jə wɑtʃɪŋ maɪ ɛvɹi muv? jəɹ dʒʌst əfɹeɪɾ əl faɪn ə naɪf." ət ðə lʊk ɪn ði æksɛptɪdz aɪz, hi læft əɡɛn. "fɔɹ maɪsɛlf, wʊmən. fəɹ maɪsɛlf. lɛd mi tə jəɹ ɡɑɹɾən, ən jəɹ wɑtʃɪŋ aɪz."

The man rumbled a bitter laugh. "With two or three of you watching my every move? You're just afraid I'll find a knife." At the look in the Accepted's eyes, he laughed again. "For myself, woman. For myself. Lead me to your garden, and your watching eyes."

ði æksɛptɪd tʌtʃt ɪz ɑɹm laɪtli, ən lɛɾ ɪm əweɪ.

The Accepted touched his arm lightly, and led him away.

"lɑɡən," ɪleɪn sɛd wən i wɑz ɡɔn.

"Logain," Elayne said when he was gone.

"ðə fɔls dʒɹæɡən!"

"The false Dragon!"

"hi hæz bɪn dʒɛntəld, ɛɡwin. hiz noʊ mɔɹ deɪnʒɝəs ðən ɛni ʌðɝ mæn, naʊ. bʌɾ aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ siɪŋ ɪm bɪfɔɹ, wən ɪt tʊk sɪks ɛɛs sədaɪ tə kip ɪm fɹəm wildɪŋ ðə paʊɝ ən dɪstʃɹɔɪɪŋ əs ɔl." ʃi ʃɪvɝd.

"He has been gentled, Egwene. He is no more dangerous than any other man, now. But I remember seeing him before, when it took six Aes Sedai to keep him from wielding the Power and destroying us all." She shivered.

ɛɡwin dɪd, tu. ðət wɑz wʌt ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ wəd də tə ɹænd.

Egwene did, too. That was what the Red Ajah would do to Rand.

"du ðeɪ ɔlweɪz əv tə bi dʒɛntəld?" ʃi æskt. ɪleɪn stɛɹɾ ət hɝ, maʊθ əɡeɪp, ən ʃi kwɪkli æɾəd, "ɪɾ ɪz dʒʌs ðəɾ aɪd θɪŋk ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wəd faɪn səm ʌðɝ weɪ tə dil wɪð ðɛm. æneɪjə ən mɔɪɹeɪn boʊθ sɛd ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst fits ə ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz ɹikwaɪɝd mɛn ən wɪmən wɝkɪŋ təɡɛðɝ wɪð ðə paʊɝ. aɪ dʒʌs θɔt ðeɪd tʃɹaɪ tə faɪn ə weɪ."

"Do they always have to be gentled?" she asked. Elayne stared at her, mouth agape, and she quickly added, "It is just that I'd think the Aes Sedai would find some other way to deal with them. Anaiya and Moiraine both said the greatest feats of the Age of Legends required men and women working together with the Power. I just thought they'd try to find a way."

"wɛl, də nɑt lɛɾ ɛni ɹɛd sɪstɝ hɪɹ jə θɪŋkɪŋ ɪɾ əlaʊd. ɛɡwin, ðeɪ dɪd tʃɹaɪ. fəɹ θɹi hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz æftɝ ðə waɪt taʊɝ wɑz bɪlt, ðeɪ tʃɹaɪd. ðeɪ ɡeɪv ʌp kəz ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə faɪnd. kʌm ɑn. aɪ wɑn jə tə mit mɪn. nɑɾ ɪn ðə ɡɑɹɾən wɛɹ lɑɡən ɪz ɡoʊɪŋ, θæŋk ðə laɪt."

"Well, do not let any Red sister hear you thinking it aloud. Egwene, they did try. For three hundred years after the White Tower was built, they tried. They gave up because there was nothing to find. Come on. I want you to meet Min. Not in the garden where Logain is going, thank the Light."

ðə neɪm saʊndəd veɪɡli fəmɪljɝ tə ɛɡwin, ən wən ʃi sɔ ðə jʌŋ wʊmən, ʃi nu waɪ. ðəɹ wɑz ə nɛɹoʊ stʃɹim ɪn ðə ɡɑɹɾən, wɪð ə loʊ stoʊn bɹɪdʒ oʊvɝ ɪt, ən mɪn sæt kɹɔs-lɛɡəɾ ɑn ðə wɔl ə ðə bɹɪdʒ. ʃi wɔɹ ə mænz taɪt bɹitʃɪz ən bæɡi ʃɝt, ən wɪð əɹ dɑɹk hɛɹ kʌt ʃɔɹt ʃi kəɾ ɔlmoʊs pæs fəɹ ə bɔɪ, ðoʊ ən ʌnkɑmənli pɹɪɾi wʌn. ə ɡɹeɪ koʊt leɪ bɪsaɪɾ əɹ ɑn ðə koʊpɪŋ.

The name sounded vaguely familiar to Egwene, and when she saw the young woman, she knew why. There was a narrow stream in the garden, with a low stone bridge over it, and Min sat cross-legged on the wall of the bridge. She wore a man's tight breeches and baggy shirt, and with her dark hair cut short she could almost pass for a boy, though an uncommonly pretty one. A gray coat lay beside her on the coping.

"aɪ noʊ ju," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ju wɝkt ət ði ɪn ɪn bɛɹlən." ə laɪt bɹiz ɹɪfəl ðə wɔɾɝ bɪniθ ðə bɹɪdʒ, ən ɡɹeɪwɪŋz wɔɹbəld ɪn ðə tʃɹiz ə ðə ɡɑɹɾən.

"I know you," Egwene said. "You worked at the inn in Baerlon." A light breeze riffled the water beneath the bridge, and graywings warbled in the trees of the garden.

mɪn smaɪld. "æn jə wɝ wʌn ə ðoʊz u bɹɔt ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz daʊn ɑn əs tə bɝn ɪt daʊn. noʊ, doʊnt wɝi. ðə mɛsənʒɝ u keɪm tə fɛtʃ mi bɹɔɾ ɪnʌf ɡoʊl ðət mæstɝ fɪtʃ ɪz bɪldɪŋ ɪt bæk əɡɛn twaɪs əz bɪɡ. ɡʊd mɔɹnɪŋ, ɪleɪn. nɑt slævɪŋ oʊvɝ jəɹ lɛsənz? əɹ oʊvɝ səm pɑts?" ɪt wɑz sɛɾ ɪn ə bæntɝɪŋ toʊn, əz bɪtwin fɹɛnz, əz ɪleɪnz ænsɝɪŋ ɡɹɪn pɹuvd.

Min smiled. "And you were one of those who brought the Darkfriends down on us to burn it down. No, don't worry. The messenger who came to fetch me brought enough gold that Master Fitch is building it back again twice as big. Good morning, Elayne. Not slaving over your lessons? Or over some pots?" It was said in a bantering tone, as between friends, as Elayne's answering grin proved.

"aɪ si ʃɛɹiəm əz nɑt jɛt mænədʒ tə ɡɛt jə ɪndə ə dʒɹɛs."

"I see Sheriam has not yet managed to get you into a dress."

mɪnz læf wɑz wɪkəd. "ɪm noʊ nɑvəs." ʃi meɪɾ əɹ vɔɪs skwiki. "jɛs, ɛɛs sədaɪ. noʊ, ɛɛs sədaɪ. meɪ aɪ swip ənʌðɝ flɔɹ, ɛɛs sədaɪ? aɪ," ʃi sɛd, ɹɪzumɪŋ əɹ oʊn loʊ vɔɪs, "kloʊð maɪsɛlf ðə weɪ aɪ wɑnt." ʃi tɝn tə ɛɡwin. "ɪz ɹænd wɛl?"

Min's laugh was wicked. "I'm no novice." She made her voice squeaky. "Yes, Aes Sedai. No, Aes Sedai. May I sweep another floor, Aes Sedai? I," she said, resuming her own low voice, "clothe myself the way I want." She turned to Egwene. "Is Rand well?"

ɛɡwinz maʊθ taɪɾənd. hi ʃəd wɛɹ ɹæmz hɔɹnz laɪk ə tʃɹɑlɑk, ʃi θɔɾ æŋɡɹəli. "aɪ wɑz sɑɹi wən jəɹ ɪn kɑt faɪɝ, ən aɪm ɡlæd mæstɝ fɪtʃ wɑz eɪbəl tə ɹibɪld. waɪ hæv jə kʌm tə tɑɹ vəlɑn? ɪts klɪɹ jə də nɑt min tə bi ən ɛɛs sədaɪ." mɪn ɑɹtʃt ən aɪbɹaʊ ɪn wʌɾ ɛɡwin wɑz ʃʊɹ wɑz əmjuzmənt.

Egwene's mouth tightened. He should wear ram's horns like a Trolloc, she thought angrily. "I was sorry when your inn caught fire, and I am glad Master Fitch was able to rebuild. Why have you come to Tar Valon? It's clear you do not mean to be an Aes Sedai." Min arched an eyebrow in what Egwene was sure was amusement.

"ʃi laɪks hɪm," ɪleɪn ɪkspleɪnd.

"She likes him," Elayne explained.

"aɪ noʊ." mɪn ɡlænst əɾ ɛɡwin, ən fəɹ ən ɪnstən ɛɡwin θɔt ʃi sɔ sædnəs - əɹ ɹəɡɹɛt? - ɪn əɹ aɪz. "aɪ æm hɪɹ," mɪn sɛd kɛɹfəli, "bɪkɔz aɪ wɑz sɛn fɔɹ, ən wɑz ɡɪvən ðə tʃɔɪs bɪtwin ɹaɪɾɪŋ ən kʌmɪŋ taɪɾ ɪn ə sæk."

"I know." Min glanced at Egwene, and for an instant Egwene thought she saw sadness - or regret? - in her eyes. "I am here," Min said carefully, "because I was sent for, and was given the choice between riding and coming tied in a sack."

"ju ɔlweɪz ɪɡzædʒɝeɪɾ ɪt," ɪleɪn sɛd. "ʃɛɹiəm sədaɪ sɔ ðə lɛɾɝ, ən ʃi sɛz ɪt wɑz ə ɹɪkwɛst. mɪn siz θɪŋz, ɛɡwin. ðæts waɪ ʃiz hɪɹ; soʊ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ kən stʌɾi haʊ ʃi dʌz ɪt. ɪɾ ɪzən ðə paʊɝ."
