"You always exaggerate it," Elayne said. "Sheriam Sedai saw the letter, and she says it was a request. Min sees things, Egwene. That's why she's here; so the Aes Sedai can study how she does it. It isn't the Power."

"ɹɪkwɛst," mɪn snɔɹɾɪd. "wɛn ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹɪkwɛsts jəɹ pɹɛzəns, ɪts laɪk ə kəmæn fɹəm ə kwin wɪð ə hʌnʒɹəd soʊlʒɝz tə bæk ɪɾ ʌp."

"Request," Min snorted. "When an Aes Sedai requests your presence, it's like a command from a queen with a hundred soldiers to back it up."

"ɛvɹibɑɾi siz θɪŋz," ɛɡwin sɛd.

"Everybody sees things," Egwene said.

ɪleɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "nɑt laɪk mɪn. ʃi siz - ɔʊɹəz - ɝaʊn pipəl. ən ɪmədʒəz."

Elayne shook her head. "Not like Min. She sees - auras - around people. And images."

"nɑɾ ɔl ðə taɪm," mɪn pʊɾ ɪn. "nɑɾ ɝaʊn ɛvɹibɑɾi."

"Not all the time," Min put in. "Not around everybody."

"ænd ʃi kən ɹid θɪŋz əbaʊt jə fɹəm ðɛm, ðoʊ aɪm nɑt ʃʊɹ ʃi ɔlweɪz tɛlz ðə tʃɹuθ. ʃi sɛɾ aɪɾ əv tə ʃɛɹ maɪ hʌzbənd wɪð tu ʌðɝ wɪmən, ən aɪd nɛvɝ pʊɾ ʌp wɪð ðæt. ʃi dʒʌs læfs, ən sɛz ɪt wɑz nɛvɝ əɹ aɪdiə ʌv haʊ tə ɹʌn θɪŋz, iðɝ. bʌt ʃi sɛɾ aɪ wəd bi ə kwin bɪfɔɹ ʃi nu hu aɪ wɑz; ʃi sɛd ʃi sɔ ə kɹaʊn, ən ɪt wɑz ðə ɹoʊz kɹaʊn ʌv ændɝ."

"And she can read things about you from them, though I'm not sure she always tells the truth. She said I'd have to share my husband with two other women, and I'd never put up with that. She just laughs, and says it was never her idea of how to run things, either. But she said I would be a queen before she knew who I was; she said she saw a crown, and it was the Rose Crown of Andor."

dɪspaɪt hɝsɛlf, ɛɡwin æskt, "wʌt dʒju si wən jə lʊk ət mi?"

Despite herself, Egwene asked, "What do you see when you look at me?"

mɪn ɡlænst ət hɝ. "ə waɪt fleɪm, ænd. . . . oʊ, ɔl sɔɹts ə θɪŋz. ɪdnt noʊ wʌɾ ɪt minz."

Min glanced at her. "A white flame, and. . . . Oh, all sorts of things. Idon't know what it means."

"ʃi sɛz ðəɾ ə ɡɹeɪt dil," ɪleɪn sɛd dʒɹaɪli. "wʌn ə ðə θɪŋz ʃi sɛd ʃi sɔ lʊkɪŋ ət mi wɑz ə sɛvɝd hænd. nɑt maɪn, ʃi sɛz. ʃi kleɪmz ʃi dʌz nɑt noʊ wʌɾ ɪt minz, iðɝ."

"She says that a great deal," Elayne said dryly. "One of the things she said she saw looking at me was a severed hand. Not mine, she says. She claims she does not know what it means, either."

"bɪkɔz aɪ doʊnt," mɪn sɛd. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt hæf ʌv ɪt minz."

"Because I don't," Min said. "I don't know what half of it means."

ðə kɹʌntʃ ə buts ɑn ðə wɔk bɹɔɾ əm ɝaʊn tə lʊk ət tu jʌŋ mɛn wɪð ðɛɹ ʃɝts ən koʊts əkɹɔs ðɛɹ ɑɹmz, livɪŋ swɛɾi tʃɛsts bɛɹ, ən skæbɑɹɾɪd sɔɹdz ɪn ðɛɹ hænz. ɛɡwin faʊn hɝsɛlf stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə moʊs hænsəm mæn ʃi hæɾ ɛvɝ sin. tɔl ən slɪm, bʌt hɑɹd, hi muvd wɪð ə kæt-laɪk ɡɹeɪs. ʃi sʌɾənli ɹilaɪzd i wɑz boʊɪŋ oʊvɝ əɹ hænd - ʃi hæd nɑɾ ivən fɛlt ɪm teɪk ɪɾ ɪn ɪz - ən fʌmbəld ɪn əɹ maɪn fəɹ ðə neɪm ʃi hæd hɝd.

The crunch of boots on the walk brought them around to look at two young men with their shirts and coats across their arms, leaving sweaty chests bare, and scabbarded swords in their hands. Egwene found herself staring at the most handsome man she had ever seen. Tall and slim, but hard, he moved with a cat-like grace. She suddenly realized he was bowing over her hand - she had not even felt him take it in his - and fumbled in her mind for the name she had heard.

"ɡɑləd," ʃi mɝmɝd. hɪz dɑɹk aɪz stɛɹd bæk ɪndə hɝz. hi wɑz oʊldɝ ðən ʃi. oʊldɝ ðən ɹænd. ət ðə θɔɾ ə ɹænd, ʃi ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ ən keɪm tə hɝsɛlf.

"Galad," she murmured. His dark eyes stared back into hers. He was older than she. Older than Rand. At the thought of Rand, she gave a start and came to herself.

"æn aɪm ɡɔɪn" - ði ʌðɝ jʌŋ mæn ɡɹɪnd - "sɪns aɪ doʊn θɪŋk jə hɝd ðə fɝs taɪm." mɪn wɑz ɡɹɪnɪŋ, tu, ən oʊnli ɪleɪn wɔɹ ə fɹaʊn.

"And I am Gawyn" - the other young man grinned - "since I don't think you heard the first time." Min was grinning, too, and only Elayne wore a frown.

ɛɡwin əbɹʌpli ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ əɹ hænd, stɪl hɛl baɪ ɡɑləd, ən fɹiɾ ɪt.

Egwene abruptly remembered her hand, still held by Galad, and freed it.

"ɪf jəɹ duɾiz əlaʊ," ɡɑləd sɛd, "aɪ wəd laɪk tə si jə əɡɛn, ɛɡwin. wi kəd wɔk, əɹ ɪf jə əbteɪn pɝmɪʃən tə liv ðə taʊɝ, wi kəd pɪknɪk aʊtsaɪd ðə sɪɾi."

"If your duties allow," Galad said, "I would like to see you again, Egwene. We could walk, or if you obtain permission to leave the Tower, we could picnic outside the city."

"ðæt - ðət wəd bi naɪs." ʃi wɑz ənkʌmftəbli əwɛɹ ə ði ʌðɝz, mɪn ən ɡɔɪn stɪl wɪð ðɛɹ əmjuzd ɡɹɪnz, ɪleɪn stɪl wɪð əɹ skaʊl. ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə sɛɾəl hɝsɛlf, tə θɪŋk ə ɹænd. hiz soʊ . . . bjuɾəfəl. ʃi ɡeɪv ə dʒʌmp, hæf əfɹeɪd ʃi hæd spoʊkən əlaʊd.

"That - that would be nice." She was uncomfortably aware of the others, Min and Gawyn still with their amused grins, Elayne still with her scowl. She tried to settle herself, to think of Rand. He's so . . . beautiful. She gave a jump, half afraid she had spoken aloud.

"əntɪl ðɛn." faɪnəli teɪkɪŋ ɪz aɪz fɹəm hɝz, ɡɑləd baʊd tə ɪleɪn. "sɪstɝ." laɪð əz ə bleɪd, hi stʃɹoʊld ɑn əkɹɔs ðə bɹɪdʒ.

"Until then." Finally taking his eyes from hers, Galad bowed to Elayne. "Sister." Lithe as a blade, he strolled on across the bridge.

"ðæt wʌn," mɪn mɝmɝd, piɹɪŋ æftɝ hɪm, "wɪl ɔlweɪz də wʌɾ ɪz ɹaɪt. noʊ mæɾɝ u ɪt hɝts."

"That one," Min murmured, peering after him, "will always do what is right. No matter who it hurts."

"sɪstɝ?" ɛɡwin sɛd. ɪleɪnz skaʊl hæd lɛsən oʊnli slaɪtli. "aɪ θɔɾ i wɑz jɔɹ. . . . aɪ min, ðə weɪ jəɹ fɹaʊnɪŋ. . . ." ʃi hæd θɔɾ ɪleɪn wɑz dʒɛləs, ən ʃi stɪl wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ.

"Sister?" Egwene said. Elayne's scowl had lessened only slightly. "I thought he was your. . . . I mean, the way you're frowning. . . ." She had thought Elayne was jealous, and she still was not sure.

"aɪ æm nɑɾ ɪz sɪstɝ," ɪleɪn sɛd fɝmli. "aɪ ɹəfjuz tə bi."

"I am not his sister," Elayne said firmly. "I refuse to be."

"aʊɝ fɑðɝ wɑz ɪz fɑðɝ," ɡɔɪn sɛd dʒɹaɪli. "ju kænɑt dɪnaɪ ðæt, ənlɛs jə wɑnə kɔl mʌðɝ ə laɪɝ, ən ðæt, aɪ θɪŋk, wəd teɪk mɔɹ nɝv ðən wɪv bɪtwin ʌs."

"Our father was his father," Gawyn said dryly. "You cannot deny that, unless you want to call Mother a liar, and that, I think, would take more nerve than we have between us."

fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm ɛɡwin ɹilaɪz ðəɾ i hæd ðə seɪm ɹɛɾɪʃ ɡoʊl hɛɹ əz ɪleɪn, ðoʊ dɑɹkən ən kɝl baɪ swɛt.

For the first time Egwene realized that he had the same reddish gold hair as Elayne, though darkened and curled by sweat.

"mɪn ɪz ɹaɪt," ɪleɪn sɛd. "ɡɑləɾ əz nɑt ðə smɔləs pɑɹɾ ə hjumænɪɾi ɪn hɪm. hi teɪks ɹaɪɾ əbʌv mɝsi, əɹ pɪɾi, ɔɹ. . . . hiz noʊ mɔɹ hjumən ðən ə tʃɹɑlɑk."

"Min is right," Elayne said. "Galad has not the smallest part of humanity in him. He takes right above mercy, or pity, or. . . . He is no more human than a Trolloc."

ɡɔɪnz ɡɹɪn keɪm bæk. "aɪ də nɑt noʊ əbaʊt ðæt. nɑt fɹəm ðə weɪ hi wɑz lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɛɡwin, hɪɹ." hi kɑɾ əɹ lʊk, ən ɪz sɪstɝz, ən hɛld ʌp ɪz hænz əz ɪf tə fɛn əm ɔf wɪð ɪz ʃið sɔɹd. "bɪsaɪdz, hiz ðə bɛs hænd wɪð ə sɔɹɾ aɪv ɛvɝ sin. ðə wɔɹɾɝz oʊnli nid ʃoʊ hɪm sʌmθɪŋ wʌns, ən hiz lɝn ɪt. ðeɪ swɛt mi nɪɹli tə dɛθ tə lɝn hæf wʌt ɡɑləd dʌz wɪθaʊt tʃɹaɪɪŋ."

Gawyn's grin came back. "I do not know about that. Not from the way he was looking at Egwene, here." He caught her look, and his sister's, and held up his hands as if to fend them off with his sheathed sword. "Besides, he has the best hand with a sword I've ever seen. The Warders only need show him something once, and he's learned it. They sweat me nearly to death to learn half what Galad does without trying."

"æn biɪŋ ɡʊd wɪð ə sɔɹɾ ɪz ɪnʌf?" ɪleɪn snɪft. "mɛn! ɛɡwin, əz jə meɪ hæv ɡɛst, ðɪs dɪsɡɹəsfəli ənkloʊð lʌmɑks ɪz maɪ bɹʌðɝ. ɡɔɪn, ɛɡwin noʊz ɹænd ælθɹ. ʃiz fɹəm ðə seɪm vɪlədʒ."

"And being good with a sword is enough?" Elayne sniffed. "Men! Egwene, as you may have guessed, this disgracefully unclothed lummox is my brother. Gawyn, Egwene knows Rand al'Thor. She is from the same village."

"ɪz ʃi? wɑz i ɹɪli bɔɹn ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, ɛɡwin?"

"Is she? Was he really born in the Two Rivers, Egwene?"

ɛɡwin meɪd hɝsɛlf nɑd kɑmli. wʌt dʌz i noʊ? "ʌv kɔɹs, hi wɑz. aɪ ɡɹu ʌp wɪð hɪm."

Egwene made herself nod calmly. What does he know? "Of course, he was. I grew up with him."

"ʌv kɔɹs," ɡɔɪn sɛd sloʊli. "sʌtʃ ə stʃɹeɪnʒ fɛloʊ. ə ʃɛpɝd, hi sɛd, ðoʊ hi nɛvɝ lʊkt əɹ æktəd laɪk ɛni ʃɛpɝɾ aɪ ɛvɝ sɔ. stʃɹeɪnʒ. aɪ hæv mɛɾ ɔl sɔɹts ə pipəl, ən ðeɪv mɛt ɹænd ælθɹ. səm də nɑɾ ivən noʊ hɪz neɪm, bʌt ðə dɪskɹɪpʃən kəd nɑt bi ɛniwʌn ɛls, ən hiz ʃɪftəɾ ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðɛɹ lɪvz. ðəɹ wɑz ən oʊl fɑɹmɝ u keɪm tə keɪɛmlɪn dʒʌs tə si lɑɡən, wən lɑɡən wɑz bɹɔt θɹu ɑn ɪz weɪ hɪɹ; jɛt ðə fɑɹmɝ steɪd tə stæn fəɹ mʌðɝ wən ðə ɹaɪəts stɑɹɾəd. kəz ʌv ə jʌŋ mæn ɔf tə si ðə wɝld, hu meɪɾ ɪm θɪŋk ðəɹ wɑz mɔɹ tə laɪf ðən ɪz fɑɹm. ɹænd ælθɹ. jə kəɾ ɔlmoʊs θɪŋk i wɑz tɑvɝən. ɪleɪɾə ɪz sɝɾənli ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn hɪm. aɪ wʌndɝ ɪf miɾɪŋ ɪm wɪl ʃɪft əɹ laɪvz ɪn ðə pæɾɝn?"

"Of course," Gawyn said slowly. "Such a strange fellow. A shepherd, he said, though he never looked or acted like any shepherd I ever saw. Strange. I have met all sorts of people, and they've met Rand al'Thor. Some do not even know his name, but the description could not be anyone else, and he's shifted every one of their lives. There was an old farmer who came to Caemlyn just to see Logain, when Logain was brought through on his way here; yet the farmer stayed to stand for Mother when the riots started. Because of a young man off to see the world, who made him think there was more to life than his farm. Rand al'Thor. You could almost think he was ta'veren. Elaida is certainly interested in him. I wonder if meeting him will shift our lives in the Pattern?"

ɛɡwin lʊkt əɾ ɪleɪn ən mɪn. ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ðeɪ kəd nɑɾ əv ə klu ðət ɹænd ɹɪli wɑz tɑvɝən. ʃi hæd nɛvɝ ɹɪli θɔɾ əbaʊt ðət pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt bɪfɔɹ; hi wɑz ɹænd, ən i hæd bɪn kɝst wɪð ði əbɪləɾi tə tʃænəl. bʌt tɑvɝən dɪd muv pipəl, wɛðɝ ðeɪ wɑntəd tə bi muvd əɹ nɑt. "aɪ ɹɪli də laɪk ju," ʃi sɛɾ əbɹʌpli, ɪnkluɾɪŋ boʊθ ɡɝlz ɪn əɹ dʒɛstʃɝ. "aɪ wɑnə bi jəɹ fɹɛnd."

Egwene looked at Elayne and Min. She was sure they could not have a clue that Rand really was ta'veren. She had never really thought about that part of it before; he was Rand, and he had been cursed with the ability to channel. But ta'veren did move people, whether they wanted to be moved or not. "I really do like you," she said abruptly, including both girls in her gesture. "I want to be your friend."

"æn aɪ wɑnə bi jʊɹz," ɪleɪn sɛd.

"And I want to be yours," Elayne said.

ɪmpʌlsɪvli, ɛɡwin hʌɡd hɝ, ən ðən mɪn dʒʌmp daʊn, ən ðə θɹi ʌv əm stʊd ðəɹ ɑn ðə bɹɪdʒ hʌɡɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝ ɔl təɡɛðɝ.

Impulsively, Egwene hugged her, and then Min jumped down, and the three of them stood there on the bridge hugging one another all together.

"wi θɹi ɑɹ taɪd təɡɛðɝ," mɪn sɛd, "ænd wi kænɑt lɛɾ ɛni mæn ɡɛɾ ɪn ðə weɪ ʌv ðæt. nɑɾ ivən hɪm."

"We three are tied together," Min said, "and we cannot let any man get in the way of that. Not even him."

"wʊd wʌn ə jə maɪn tɛlɪŋ mi wʌt ðɪs ɪz ɔl əbaʊt?" ɡɔɪn ɪnkwaɪɝd dʒɛnli.

"Would one of you mind telling me what this is all about?" Gawyn inquired gently.

"ju wəd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd," hɪz sɪstɝ sɛd, ən ðə θɹi ɡɝlz ɔl kɑɾ ə fɪɾ ə ðə ɡɪɡəlz.

"You would not understand," his sister said, and the three girls all caught a fit of the giggles.

ɡɔɪn skɹætʃt ɪz hɛd, ðən ʃʊk ɪt. "wɛl, ɪf ɪts ɛniθɪŋ tə də wɪð ɹænd ælθɹ, bi ʃʊɹ jə doʊn lɛɾ ɪleɪɾə hɪɹ ʌv ɪt. ʃiz bɪn ət mi laɪk ə waɪtkloʊk kwɛstʃənɝ θɹi taɪmz sɪns wi ɝaɪvd. aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk ʃi minz ɪm ɛni - " hi ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt; ðəɹ wɑz ə wʊmən kɹɔsɪŋ ðə ɡɑɹɾən, ə wʊmən ɪn ə ɹɛd-fɹɪnd ʃɔl. " 'neɪm ðə dɑɹk wʌn,' " hi kwoʊɾəd, " 'æn i əpɪɹz.' aɪ də nɑt niɾ ənʌðɝ lɛktʃɝ əbaʊt wɛɹɪŋ maɪ ʃɝt wən aɪm aʊɾ ə ðə pɹæktəs jɑɹdz. ɡʊd mɔɹnɪŋ tə jə ɔl."

Gawyn scratched his head, then shook it. "Well, if it has anything to do with Rand al'Thor, be sure you don't let Elaida hear of it. She has been at me like a Whitecloak Questioner three times since we arrived. I do not think she means him any - " He gave a start; there was a woman crossing the garden, a woman in a red-fringed shawl. " 'Name the Dark One,' " he quoted, " 'and he appears.' I do not need another lecture about wearing my shirt when I'm out of the practice yards. Good morning to you all."

ɪleɪɾə spɛɹɾ ə ɡlæns fəɹ ðə dɪpɑɹɾɪŋ ɡɔɪn əz ʃi keɪm ʌp ðə bɹɪdʒ. ʃi wɑz ə hænsəm wʊmən ɹæðɝ ðən bjuɾəfəl, ɛɡwin θɔt, bʌt ðəɾ eɪdʒləs lʊk mɑɹkt əɹ əz ʃʊɹli əz əɹ ʃɔl; oʊnli ðə nuəst-meɪd sɪstɝz lækt ɪt. wən əɹ ɡeɪz swɛpt oʊvɝ ɛɡwin, pɔzɪŋ oʊnli ə moʊmənt, ɛɡwin sʌɾənli sɔ ə hɑɹdnəs ɪn ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ʃi hæɾ ɔlweɪz θɔɾ ə mɔɪɹeɪn əz stʃɹɔŋ, stil ʌndɝ sɪlk, bʌɾ ɪleɪɾə dɪspɛnst wɪð ðə sɪlk.

Elaida spared a glance for the departing Gawyn as she came up the bridge. She was a handsome woman rather than beautiful, Egwene thought, but that ageless look marked her as surely as her shawl; only the newest-made sisters lacked it. When her gaze swept over Egwene, pausing only a moment, Egwene suddenly saw a hardness in the Aes Sedai. She had always thought of Moiraine as strong, steel under silk, but Elaida dispensed with the silk.

"ɪleɪɾə," ɪleɪn sɛd, "ðɪs ɪz ɛɡwin. ʃi wɑz bɔɹn wɪð ðə siɾ ɪn hɝ, tu. ən ʃiz ɔlɹɛɾi hæd səm lɛsənz, soʊ ʃiz əz fɑɹ əlɔŋ əz aɪ æm. ɪleɪɾə?"

"Elaida," Elayne said, "this is Egwene. She was born with the seed in her, too. And she has already had some lessons, so she is as far along as I am. Elaida?"

ði ɛɛs sədaɪz feɪs wɑz blæŋk ən ənɹiɾəbəl. "ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, tʃaɪld, aɪm kaʊnsəlɝ tə ðə kwin jəɹ mʌðɝ, bʌt ðɪs ɪz ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ən ju, ə nɑvəs." mɪn meɪɾ əz ɪf tə ɡoʊ, bʌɾ ɪleɪɾə stɑpt əɹ wɪð ə ʃɑɹp, "steɪ, ɡɝl. aɪ wəd spik wɪð ju."

The Aes Sedai's face was blank and unreadable. "In Caemlyn, child, I am councilor to the Queen your mother, but this is the White Tower, and you, a novice." Min made as if to go, but Elaida stopped her with a sharp, "Stay, girl. I would speak with you."

"aɪv noʊn jə ɔl maɪ laɪf, ɪleɪɾə," ɪleɪn sɛɾ ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli. "ju wɑtʃt mi ɡɹoʊ ʌp, ən meɪd ðə ɡɑɹɾənz blum ɪn wɪntɝ soʊ aɪ kəd pleɪ."

"I've known you all my life, Elaida," Elayne said incredulously. "You watched me grow up, and made the gardens bloom in winter so I could play."

"tʃaɪld, ðəɹ jə wɝ ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ. hɪɹ jə ɑɹ ə nɑvəs. jə mʌs lɝn ðæt. jəl bi ɡɹeɪt wʌn deɪ, bʌt jə mʌs lɝn!"

"Child, there you were the Daughter-Heir. Here you are a novice. You must learn that. You will be great one day, but you must learn!"

"jɛs, ɛɛs sədaɪ."

"Yes, Aes Sedai."

ɛɡwin wɑz əstaʊndɪd. ɪf sʌmwʌn hæd snʌbd əɹ soʊ bɪfɔɹ ʌðɝz, ʃi wʊɾə bɪn ɪn ə fjʊɹi.

Egwene was astounded. If someone had snubbed her so before others, she would have been in a fury.

"naʊ, ɔf wɪð boʊθ ə ju." ə ɡɔŋ bɪɡæn tə toʊl, dip ən sɑnɝəs, ən ɪleɪɾə tɪltəɾ əɹ hɛd. ðə sʌn stʊd hæfweɪ tə ɪts pɪnəkəl. "haɪ," ɪleɪɾə sɛd. "ju mʌs hɝi, ɪf jə də nɑt wɑn fɝðɝ ædmɑnɪʃmənt. ən ɪleɪn? si ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz ɪn əɹ stʌɾi æftɝ jəɹ tʃɔɹz. ə nɑvəs dʌz nɑt spik tə ɛɛs sədaɪ ənlɛs bɪɾən tə. ɹʌn, boʊθ ə ju. jəl bi leɪt. ɹʌn!"

"Now, off with both of you." A gong began to toll, deep and sonorous, and Elaida tilted her head. The sun stood halfway to its pinnacle. "High," Elaida said. "You must hurry, if you do not want further admonishment. And Elayne? See the Mistress of Novices in her study after your chores. A novice does not speak to Aes Sedai unless bidden to. Run, both of you. You will be late. Run!"

ðeɪ ɹæn, hoʊldɪŋ ðɛɹ skɝts ʌp. ɛɡwin lʊkt əɾ ɪleɪn. ɪleɪn hæd tu spɑts ə kʌlɝ ɪn əɹ tʃiks ən ə dɪtɝmən lʊk ɑn əɹ feɪs.

They ran, holding their skirts up. Egwene looked at Elayne. Elayne had two spots of color in her cheeks and a determined look on her face.

"aɪ wɪl bi ɛɛs sədaɪ," ɪleɪn sɛd sɔfli, bʌɾ ɪt saʊndəd laɪk ə pɹɑməs.

"I will be Aes Sedai," Elayne said softly, but it sounded like a promise.

bɪhaɪn ðɛm, ɛɡwin hɝd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ bɪɡɪn, "aɪ æm ɡɪvən tə ʌndɝstænd, ɡɝl, ðət jə wɝ bɹɔt hɪɹ baɪ mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ."

Behind them, Egwene heard the Aes Sedai begin, "I am given to understand, girl, that you were brought here by Moiraine Sedai."

ʃi wɑntəd tə steɪ ən lɪsən, tə hɪɹ ɪf ɪleɪɾə æskt əbaʊt ɹænd, bʌt haɪ ɹæŋ θɹu ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ən ʃi wɑz sʌmən tə tʃɔɹz. ʃi ɹæn əz ʃi hæd bɪn kəmændəd tə ɹʌn.

She wanted to stay and listen, to hear if Elaida asked about Rand, but High rang through the White Tower, and she was summoned to chores. She ran as she had been commanded to run.

"aɪ wɪl bi ɛɛs sədaɪ," ʃi ɡɹaʊld. ɪleɪn flæʃt ə kwɪk smaɪl ʌv ʌndɝstændɪŋ, ən ðeɪ ɹæn fæstɝ.

"I will be Aes Sedai," she growled. Elayne flashed a quick smile of understanding, and they ran faster.

mɪnz ʃɝt klʌŋ tə hɝ wən ʃi faɪnəli lɛf ðə bɹɪdʒ. nɑt swɛt fɹəm ðə sʌn, bʌt fɹəm ðə hiɾ ʌv ɪleɪɾəz kwɛstʃənz. ʃi lʊkt oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑz nɑt fɑloʊɪŋ hɝ, bʌɾ ɪleɪɾə wɑz noʊwɛɹ ɪn saɪt.

Min's shirt clung to her when she finally left the bridge. Not sweat from the sun, but from the heat of Elaida's questions. She looked over her shoulder to make sure the Aes Sedai was not following her, but Elaida was nowhere in sight.

haʊ dɪɾ ɪleɪɾə noʊ ðət mɔɪɹeɪn hæd sʌmən hɝ? mɪn hæd bɪn ʃʊɹ ðət wɑz ə sikɹət noʊn oʊnli tə hɝ, mɔɪɹeɪn, ən ʃɛɹiəm. ən ɔl ðoʊz kwɛstʃənz əbaʊt ɹænd. ɪt hæd nɑt bɪn izi kipɪŋ ə smuð feɪs ən ə stɛɾi aɪ waɪl tɛlɪŋ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ tə hɝ feɪs ðət ʃi hæd nɛvɝ hɝɾ ə hɪm ən nu nʌθɪŋ ə hɪm. wʌt dʌz ʃi wɑnt wɪð hɪm? laɪt, wʌt dʌz mɔɪɹeɪn wɑnt wɪð hɪm? wʌɾ ɪz hi? laɪt, aɪ doʊnt wɑnə fɔl ɪn lʌv wɪð ə mæn aɪv oʊnli mɛt wʌns, ən ə fɑɹmbɔɪ ət ðæt.

How did Elaida know that Moiraine had summoned her? Min had been sure that was a secret known only to her, Moiraine, and Sheriam. And all those questions about Rand. It had not been easy keeping a smooth face and a steady eye while telling an Aes Sedai to her face that she had never heard of him and knew nothing of him. What does she want with him? Light, what does Moiraine want with him? What is he? Light, I don't want to fall in love with a man I've only met once, and a farmboy at that.

"mɔɪɹeɪn, ðə laɪt blaɪn ju," ʃi mʌɾɝd, "wʌtɛvɝ jə bɹɔt mi hɪɹ fɔɹ, kʌm aʊt fɹəm wɛɹɛvɝ jəɹ haɪɾɪŋ ən tɛl mi soʊ aɪ kən ɡoʊ!"

"Moiraine, the Light blind you," she muttered, "whatever you brought me here for, come out from wherever you're hiding and tell me so I can go!"

ði oʊnli ænsɝ wɑz ðə swit sɔŋ ə ðə ɡɹeɪwɪŋz. wɪð ə ɡɹɪmɑs ʃi wɛn ɪn sɝtʃ ʌv ə pleɪs tə kul ɔf.

The only answer was the sweet song of the graywings. With a grimace she went in search of a place to cool off.


tʃæptɝ twɛntifaɪv


CHAPTER 25

kɛɹhin


Cairhien

ðə sɪɾi ʌv kɛɹhin leɪ əkɹɔs hɪlz əɡɛns ðə ɹɪvɝ ɑlɡnjə, ən ɹændz fɝst saɪɾ ʌv ɪt keɪm fɹəm ðə hɪlz tə ðə nɔɹθ, baɪ ðə laɪɾ ə ðə mɪddeɪ sʌn. ɛlɹəkeɪn tɑvəlɪn ən ðə fɪfti kɛɹhinɪn soʊlʒɝz stɪl sim laɪk ɡɑɹdz tə hɪm - ðə mɔɹ sɪns kɹɔsɪŋ ðə bɹɪdʒ ət ðə ɡeɪɛlɪn; ðeɪ bɪkeɪm mɔɹ stɪf ðə fɝðɝ saʊθ ðeɪ ɹoʊd - bʌt lɔɪəl ən hʊɹɪn dɪd nɑɾ əpɪɹ tə maɪnd, soʊ hi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə. hi stʌɾid ðə sɪɾi, əz lɑɹdʒ əz ɛni hi hæd sin. fæt ʃɪps ən bɹɔd bɑɹdʒəz fɪl ðə ɹɪvɝ, ən tɔl ɡɹænɛɝiz spɹɔld əlɔŋ ðə fɑɹ bæŋk, bʌt kɛɹhin sim tə bi leɪɾ aʊɾ ɪn ə pɹɪsaɪs ɡɹɪd bɪhaɪn ɪts haɪ, ɡɹeɪ wɔlz. ðoʊz wɔlz ðɛmsɛlvz meɪɾ ə pɝfək skwɛɹ, wɪð wʌn saɪd hɑɹɾ əlɔŋ ðə ɹɪvɝ. ɪn dʒʌst əz ɪɡzækt ə pæɾɝn, taʊɝz ɹoʊz wɪðɪn ðə wɔlz, sɔɹɪŋ əz mʌtʃ əz twɛnti taɪmz ðə haɪɾ ə ðə wɔl, jɛɾ ivən fɹəm ðə hɪlz ɹænd kəd si ðəɾ itʃ wʌn ɛndəɾ ɪn ə dʒæɡd tɑp.

The city of Cairhien lay across hills against the River Alguenya, and Rand's first sight of it came from the hills to the north, by the light of the midday sun. Elricain Tavolin and the fifty Cairhienin soldiers still seemed like guards to him - the more since crossing the bridge at the Gaelin; they became more stiff the further south they rode - but Loial and Hurin did not appear to mind, so he tried not to. He studied the city, as large as any he had seen. Fat ships and broad barges filled the river, and tall granaries sprawled along the far bank, but Cairhien seemed to be laid out in a precise grid behind its high, gray walls. Those walls themselves made a perfect square, with one side hard along the river. In just as exact a pattern, towers rose within the walls, soaring as much as twenty times the height of the wall, yet even from the hills Rand could see that each one ended in a jagged top.

aʊtsaɪd ðə sɪɾi wɔlz, sɝaʊndɪŋ əm fɹəm ɹɪvɝbæŋk tə ɹɪvɝbæŋk, leɪ ə wɔɹən ə stʃɹits, kɹɪskɹɔsɪŋ əɾ ɔl æŋɡəlz ən timɪŋ wɪð pipəl. fɔɹɡeɪt, ɹænd nu ɪt wɑz kɔld, fɹəm hʊɹɪn; wʌns ðəɹ hæd bɪn ə mɑɹkət vɪlədʒ fəɹ ɛvɹi sɪɾi ɡeɪt, bʌɾ oʊvɝ ðə jɪɹz ðeɪ hæɾ ɔl ɡɹoʊn ɪndə wʌn, ə hɑdʒpɑdʒ ə stʃɹits ən æliz ɡɹoʊɪŋ ʌp ɛvɹi wɪtʃ weɪ.

Outside the city walls, surrounding them from riverbank to riverbank, lay a warren of streets, crisscrossing at all angles and teeming with people. Foregate, Rand knew it was called, from Hurin; once there had been a market village for every city gate, but over the years they had all grown into one, a hodgepodge of streets and alleys growing up every which way.

əz ɹænd ən ði ʌðɝz ɹoʊɾ ɪndə ðoʊz dɝt stʃɹits, tɑvəlɪn pʊt səm ə hɪz soʊlʒɝz tə klɪɹɪŋ ə pæθ θɹu ðə θɹɔŋ, ʃaʊɾɪŋ ən ɝdʒɪŋ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz fɔɹwɝɾ əz ɪf tə tʃɹæmpəl ɛni hu dɪd nɑt ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ kwɪkli. pipəl muvd əsaɪd wɪð noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə ɡlæns, əz ɪf ɪt wɝ ən ɛvɹideɪ əkɝəns. ɹænd faʊn hɪmsɛlf smaɪlɪŋ, ðoʊ.

As Rand and the others rode into those dirt streets, Tavolin put some of his soldiers to clearing a path through the throng, shouting and urging their horses forward as if to trample any who did not get out of the way quickly. People moved aside with no more than a glance, as if it were an everyday occurrence. Rand found himself smiling, though.

ðə fɔɹɡeɪt pipəlz kloʊðz wɝ ʃæbi mɔɹ ɔfən ðən nɑt, jɛt mʌtʃ ʌv ɪt wɑz kʌlɝfəl, ən ðəɹ wɑz ə ɹɔkəs bʌsəl ə laɪf tə ðə pleɪs. hɔkɝz kɹaɪd ðɛɹ wɛɹz, ən ʃɑpkipɝz kɔl fəɹ pipəl tə ɪɡzæmɪn ðə ɡʊdz dɪspleɪɾ ɑn teɪbəlz bɪfɔɹ ðɛɹ ʃɑps. bɑɹbɝz, fɹut-pɛdlɝz, naɪf-ʃɑɹpənɝz, mɛn ən wɪmən ɔfɝɪŋ ə dʌzən sɝvəsəz ən ə hʌnʒɹəd θɪŋz fəɹ seɪl, wɑndɝd θɹu ðə kɹaʊdz. mjuzɪk dʒɹɪftəd θɹu ðə bæbəl fɹəm mɔɹ ðən wʌn stʃɹʌktʃɝ; ət fɝst ɹænd θɔt ðeɪ wɝ ɪnz, bʌt ðə saɪnz aʊt fɹʌn ɔl ʃoʊd mɛn pleɪɪŋ fluts əɹ hɑɹps, tʌmbəlɪŋ əɹ dʒʌɡəlɪŋ, ən lɑɹdʒ əz ðeɪ wɝ, ðeɪ hæd noʊ wɪndoʊz. moʊst ə ðə bɪldɪŋz ɪn fɔɹɡeɪt sim tə bi wʊd, haʊɛvɝ bɪɡ ðeɪ wɝ, ən ə ɡʊd mɛni lʊk nu, ɪf pʊɹli meɪd. ɹænd ɡeɪpt ət sɛvɹəl ðət stʊd sɛvən stɔɹiz əɹ mɔɹ; ðeɪ sweɪd slaɪtli, ðoʊ ðə pipəl hɝiɪŋ ɪn ən aʊt dɪd nɑt sim tə noʊɾəs.

The Foregate people's clothes were shabby more often than not, yet much of it was colorful, and there was a raucous bustle of life to the place. Hawkers cried their wares, and shopkeepers called for people to examine the goods displayed on tables before their shops. Barbers, fruit-peddlers, knife-sharpeners, men and women offering a dozen services and a hundred things for sale, wandered through the crowds. Music drifted through the babble from more than one structure; at first Rand thought they were inns, but the signs out front all showed men playing flutes or harps, tumbling or juggling, and large as they were, they had no windows. Most of the buildings in Foregate seemed to be wood, however big they were, and a good many looked new, if poorly made. Rand gaped at several that stood seven stories or more; they swayed slightly, though the people hurrying in and out did not seem to notice.

"pɛzəns," tɑvəlɪn mʌɾɝd, stɛɹɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛɾ ɪn dɪsɡʌst. "lʊk ət ðɛm, kɝʌptɪd baɪ aʊtlænd weɪz. ðeɪ ʃəd nɑt bi hɪɹ."

"Peasants," Tavolin muttered, staring straight ahead in disgust. "Look at them, corrupted by outland ways. They should not be here."

"wɛɹ ʃəd ðeɪ bi?" ɹænd æskt. ðə kɛɹhinɪn ɔfəsɝ ɡlɛɹɾ əɾ ɪm ən spɝɾ ɪz hɔɹs fɔɹwɝd, flɑɡɪŋ ət ðə kɹaʊd wɪð ɪz kwɝt.

"Where should they be?" Rand asked. The Cairhienin officer glared at him and spurred his horse forward, flogging at the crowd with his quirt.

hʊɹɪn tʌtʃt ɹændz ɑɹm. "ɪt wɑz ði il wɔɹ, lɔɹd ɹænd." hi lʊk tə meɪk ʃʊɹ nʌn ə ðə soʊlʒɝz wɝ kloʊs ɪnʌf tə hɪɹ. "mɛni ʌv ðə fɑɹmɝz wɝ əfɹeɪd tə ɡoʊ bæk tə ðɛɹ lænz nɪɹ ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝld, ən ðeɪ ɔl keɪm hɪɹ, nɪɹ ɪnʌf. ðæts waɪ ɡɔlʒɹiən əz ðə ɹɪvɝ fʊl ʌv ɡɹeɪn bɑɹdʒəz ʌp fɹəm ændɝ ən tɛɹ. ðɛɹz noʊ kɹɑps kʌmɪŋ fɹəm fɑɹmz ɪn ði is kəz ðəɹ ɑɹən ɛni fɑɹmz ɛnimɔɹ. bɛs nɑt tə mɛnʃən ɪt tə ə kɛɹhinɪn ðoʊ, maɪ lɔɹd. ðeɪ laɪk tə pɹitɛn ðə wɔɹ nɛvɝ hæpənd, əɹ ət lis ðət ðeɪ wʌn ɪt."

Hurin touched Rand's arm. "It was the Aiel War, Lord Rand." He looked to make sure none of the soldiers were close enough to hear. "Many of the farmers were afraid to go back to their lands near the Spine of the World, and they all came here, near enough. That's why Galldrian has the river full of grain barges up from Andor and Tear. There's no crops coming from farms in the east because there aren't any farms anymore. Best not to mention it to a Cairhienin though, my Lord. They like to pretend the war never happened, or at least that they won it."

dɪspaɪt tɑvəlɪnz kwɝt, ðeɪ wɝ fɔɹs tə hɔlt waɪl ə stʃɹeɪnʒ pɹəsɛʃən kɹɔs ðɛɹ pæθ. hæf ə dʌzən mɛn, biɾɪŋ tæmbɔɝz ən dænsɪŋ, lɛd ðə weɪ fəɹ ə stʃɹɪŋ ə hjudʒ pʌpəts, itʃ hæf əɡɛn əz tɔl əz ðə mɛn u wɝkt əm wɪð lɔŋ poʊlz. dʒaɪən kɹaʊn fɪɡjɝz ə mɛn ən wɪmən ɪn lɔŋ, ɔɹneɪt ɹoʊbz baʊd tə ðə kɹaʊɾ əmɪd ðə ʃeɪps ə fænsɪfəl bists. ə laɪən wɪð wɪŋz. ə ɡoʊt, wɔkɪŋ ɑn ɪts haɪn lɛɡz, wɪð tu hɛdz, boʊθ ʌv wɪtʃ wɝ əpɛɹənli mɛn tə bi bɹiðɪŋ faɪɝ, fɹəm ðə kɹɪmzən stʃɹimɝz hæŋɪŋ fɹəm ðə tu maʊðz. sʌmθɪŋ ðət sim tə bi hæf kæɾ ən hæf iɡəl, ən ənʌðɝ wɪð ə bɛɹz hɛɾ ɑn ə mænz bɑɾi, wɪtʃ ɹænd tʊk tə bi ə tʃɹɑlɑk. ðə kɹaʊd tʃɪɹɾ ən læft əz ðeɪ pɹæns baɪ.

Despite Tavolin's quirt, they were forced to halt while a strange procession crossed their path. Half a dozen men, beating tambours and dancing, led the way for a string of huge puppets, each half again as tall as the men who worked them with long poles. Giant crowned figures of men and women in long, ornate robes bowed to the crowd amid the shapes of fanciful beasts. A lion with wings. A goat, walking on its hind legs, with two heads, both of which were apparently meant to be breathing fire, from the crimson streamers hanging from the two mouths. Something that seemed to be half cat and half eagle, and another with a bear's head on a man's body, which Rand took to be a Trolloc. The crowd cheered and laughed as they pranced by.

"mæn u meɪd ðət nɛvɝ sɔ ə tʃɹɑlɑk," hʊɹɪn ɡɹʌmbəld. "hɛdz tu bɪɡ, ən ɪts tu skɪni. laɪkli dɪdn bɪliv ɪn ðɛm, iðɝ, maɪ lɔɹd, ɛni mɔɹ ðən ɪn ðoʊz ʌðɝ θɪŋz. ði oʊnli mɑnstɝz ðiz fɔɹɡeɪt foʊk bɪliv ɪn ɑɹ il."

"Man who made that never saw a Trolloc," Hurin grumbled. "Head's too big, and it's too skinny. Likely didn't believe in them, either, my Lord, any more than in those other things. The only monsters these Foregate folk believe in are Aiel."

"ɑɹ ðeɪ hævɪŋ ə fɛstəvəl?" ɹænd æskt. hi dɪd nɑt si ɛni saɪn ʌv ɪɾ ʌðɝ ðən ðə pɹəsɛʃən, bʌɾ i θɔt ðət ðəɹ mʌs bi ə ɹizən fəɹ ðæt. tɑvəlɪn ɔɹɾɝd ɪz soʊlʒɝz fɔɹwɝɾ əɡɛn.

"Are they having a festival?" Rand asked. He did not see any sign of it other than the procession, but he thought that there must be a reason for that. Tavolin ordered his soldiers forward again.

"noʊ mɔɹ ðən ɛvɹi deɪ, ɹænd," lɔɪəl sɛd. wɔkɪŋ əlɔŋsaɪɾ ɪz hɔɹs, ðə blæŋkət-ɹæp tʃɛst stɪl stʃɹæp tə hɪz sæɾəl, ði oʊɡiɝ dʒɹu əz mɛni lʊks əz ðə pʌpəts hæd. səm ivən læft ən klæpt əz ðeɪ hæd fəɹ ðə pʌpəts. "aɪ fɪɹ ɡɔlʒɹiən kips ɪz pipəl kwaɪət baɪ ɛntɝteɪnɪŋ ðɛm. hi ɡɪvz ɡlimən ən mjuzɪʃənz ðə kɪŋz ɡɪft, ə baʊnti ɪn sɪlvɝ, tə pɝfɔɹm hɪɹ ɪn ðə fɔɹɡeɪt, ən i spɑnsɝz hɔɹs ɹeɪsəz daʊn baɪ ðə ɹɪvɝ ɛvɹi deɪ. ðəɹ ɑɹ faɪɹwɝks mɛni naɪts, tu." hi saʊndəd dɪsɡʌstəd. "ɛldɝ heɪmən sɛz ɡɔlʒɹiən ɪz ə dɪsɡɹeɪs." hi blɪŋkt, ɹilaɪzɪŋ wʌɾ i hæd sɛd, ən lʊkt ɝaʊn hɝidli tə si ɪf ɛni ʌv ðə soʊlʒɝz hæd hɝd. nʌn sim tə hæv.

"No more than every day, Rand," Loial said. Walking alongside his horse, the blanket-wrapped chest still strapped to his saddle, the Ogier drew as many looks as the puppets had. Some even laughed and clapped as they had for the puppets. "I fear Galldrian keeps his people quiet by entertaining them. He gives gleemen and musicians the King's Gift, a bounty in silver, to perform here in the Foregate, and he sponsors horse races down by the river every day. There are fireworks many nights, too." He sounded disgusted. "Elder Haman says Galldrian is a disgrace." He blinked, realizing what he had said, and looked around hurriedly to see if any of the soldiers had heard. None seemed to have.

"faɪɹwɝks," hʊɹɪn sɛd, nɑɾɪŋ. "ði ɪluməneɪɾɝz əv bɪlt ə tʃæptɝ haʊs hɪɹ, aɪv hɝd, ðə seɪm əz ɪn tæntʃəkoʊ. aɪ dɪdn hæf maɪn siɪŋ ðə faɪɹwɝks, wən aɪ wɑz hɪɹ bɪfɔɹ."

"Fireworks," Hurin said, nodding. "The Illuminators have built a chapter house here, I've heard, the same as in Tanchico. I didn't half mind seeing the fireworks, when I was here before."

ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. hi hæd nɛvɝ sin faɪɹwɝks ɪlæbɹəɾ ɪnʌf tə ɹikwaɪɝ ivən wʌn ɪluməneɪɾɝ. hi hæd hɝd ðeɪ oʊnli lɛf tæntʃəkoʊ tə pʊɾ ɑn dɪspleɪz fəɹ ɹulɝz. ɪt wɑz ə stʃɹeɪnʒ pleɪs i wɑz kʌmɪŋ tə.

Rand shook his head. He had never seen fireworks elaborate enough to require even one Illuminator. He had heard they only left Tanchico to put on displays for rulers. It was a strange place he was coming to.

ət ðə tɔl, skwɛɹ ɑɹtʃweɪ ʌv ðə sɪɾi ɡeɪt, tɑvəlɪn ɔɹɾɝd ə hɔlt ən dɪsmaʊntɪd baɪ ə skwɑt stoʊn bɪldɪŋ dʒʌst ɪnsaɪd ðə wɔlz. ɪt hæɾ æɹoʊ-slɪts ɪnstɛɾ ʌv wɪndoʊz, ən ə hɛvi, aɪɝn-baʊn dɔɹ.

At the tall, square archway of the city gate, Tavolin ordered a halt and dismounted by a squat stone building just inside the walls. It had arrow-slits instead of windows, and a heavy, iron-bound door.

"ə moʊmənt, maɪ lɔɹd ɹænd," ði ɔfəsɝ sɛd. tɔsɪŋ ɪz ɹeɪnz tə wʌn ə ðə soʊlʒɝz, hi dɪsəpɪɹɾ ɪnsaɪd.

"A moment, my Lord Rand," the officer said. Tossing his reins to one of the soldiers, he disappeared inside.

wɪð ə wɛɹi lʊk ət ðə soʊlʒɝz - ðeɪ sæt ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz ɹɪdʒɪdli ɪn tu lɔŋ faɪlz; ɹænd wʌndɝd wʌt ðeɪ wəd də ɪf i ən lɔɪəl ən hʊɹɪn tʃɹaɪd tə liv - hi tʊk ði ɑpɝtunəɾi tə stʌɾi ðə sɪɾi ðət leɪ bɪfɔɹ hɪm.

With a wary look at the soldiers - they sat their horses rigidly in two long files; Rand wondered what they would do if he and Loial and Hurin tried to leave - he took the opportunity to study the city that lay before him.

kɛɹhin pɹɑpɝ wɑz ə ʃɑɹp kɑntʃɹæs tə ðə keɪɑɾɪk bʌsəl ə ðə fɔɹɡeɪt. bɹɔd, peɪv stʃɹits, waɪɾ ɪnʌf tə meɪk ðə pipəl ɪn əm sim fjuɝ ðən ðeɪ wɝ, kɹɔst itʃ ʌðɝ ət ɹaɪɾ æŋɡəlz. dʒʌst əz ɪn tʃɹɛmoʊnzin, ðə hɪlz hæd bɪn kɑɹvd ən tɛɹəs tə stʃɹeɪt laɪnz. kloʊz sɪdæn tʃɛɹz, səm wɪð smɔl pɛnəns bɛɹɪŋ ðə sɪdʒəl ʌv ə haʊs, muvd wɪð dɪlɪbɝætnəs, ən kæɹɪdʒɪz ɹoʊl daʊn ðə stʃɹits sloʊli. pipəl wɛn saɪlənli ɪn dɑɹk kloʊðz, wɪð noʊ bɹaɪt kʌlɝz ɪksɛp hɪɹ ən ðəɹ slæʃɪz əkɹɔs ðə bɹɛst ə koʊɾ əɹ dʒɹɛs. ðə mɔɹ slæʃɪz, ðə mɔɹ pɹaʊdli ðə wɛɹɝ muvd, bʌt noʊ wʌn læft, əɹ ivən smaɪld. ðə bɪldɪŋz ɑn ðɛɹ tɛɹəsəz wɝ ɔl ə stoʊn, ən ði ɔɹnəmɛnteɪʃən wɑz stʃɹeɪt-laɪn ən ʃɑɹp-æŋɡəld. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ hɔkɝz əɹ pɛdlɝz ɪn ðə stʃɹits, ən ivən ðə ʃɑps sim səbdud, wɪð oʊnli smɔl saɪnz ən noʊ wɛɹz dɪspleɪɾ aʊtsaɪd.

Cairhien proper was a sharp contrast to the chaotic bustle of the Foregate. Broad, paved streets, wide enough to make the people in them seem fewer than they were, crossed each other at right angles. Just as in Tremonsien, the hills had been carved and terraced to straight lines. Closed sedan chairs, some with small pennants bearing the sigil of a House, moved with deliberateness, and carriages rolled down the streets slowly. People went silently in dark clothes, with no bright colors except here and there slashes across the breast of coat or dress. The more slashes, the more proudly the wearer moved, but no one laughed, or even smiled. The buildings on their terraces were all of stone, and the ornamentation was straight-lined and sharp-angled. There were no hawkers or peddlers in the streets, and even the shops seemed subdued, with only small signs and no wares displayed outside.

hi kəd si ðə ɡɹeɪt taʊɝz mɔɹ klɪɹli, naʊ. skæfəlz ə læʃt poʊlz sɝaʊndəd ðɛm, ən wɝkmɪn swɔɹmd ɑn ðə skæfəldɪŋ, leɪɪŋ nu stoʊnz tə pʊʃ ðə taʊɝz haɪɝ stɪl.

He could see the great towers more clearly, now. Scaffolds of lashed poles surrounded them, and workmen swarmed on the scaffolding, laying new stones to push the towers higher still.

"ðə tɑpləs taʊɝz ə kɛɹhin," lɔɪəl mɝmɝd sædli. "wɛl, ðeɪ wɝ tɔl ɪnʌf tə wɔɹən ðə neɪm, wʌns. wən ði il tʊk kɛɹhin, əbaʊt ðə taɪm jə wɝ bɔɹn, ðə taʊɝz bɝnd, ən kɹækt, ən fɛl. aɪ doʊn si ɛni oʊɡiɝ əmʌŋ ðə stoʊnmeɪsɑnz. noʊ oʊɡiɝ kəd laɪk wɝkɪŋ hɪɹ - ðə kɛɹhinɪn wɑnt wʌt ðeɪ wɑnt, wɪθaʊɾ ɛmbɛlɪʃmənt - bʌt ðəɹ wɝ oʊɡiɝ wən aɪ wɑz hɪɹ bɪfɔɹ."

"The Topless Towers of Cairhien," Loial murmured sadly. "Well, they were tall enough to warrant the name, once. When the Aiel took Cairhien, about the time you were born, the towers burned, and cracked, and fell. I don't see any Ogier among the stonemasons. No Ogier could like working here - the Cairhienin want what they want, without embellishment - but there were Ogier when I was here before."

tɑvəlɪn keɪm aʊt, tʃɹeɪlɪŋ ənʌðɝ ɔfəsɝ ən tu klɝks, wʌn kæɹiɪŋ ə lɑɹdʒ, wʊd-baʊn lɛdʒɝ ən ði ʌðɝ ə tʃɹeɪ wɪð ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪmpləmɛns. ðə fɹʌn ə ði ɔfəsɝz hɛd wɑz ʃeɪvən laɪk tɑvəlɪnz, ðoʊ ədvænsɪŋ bɔlnəs sim tə hæv teɪkən mɔɹ hɛɹ ðən ðə ɹeɪzɝ. boʊθ ɔfəsɝz lʊk fɹəm ɹænd tə ðə tʃɛs hɪɾən baɪ lɔɪəlz stʃɹaɪp blæŋkəɾ ən bæk əɡɛn. niðɝ æskt wʌt wɑz ʌndɝ ðə blæŋkət. tɑvəlɪn hæd lʊkt əɾ ɪɾ ɔfən ɑn ðə weɪ fɹəm tʃɹɛmoʊnzin, bʌɾ i hæd nɛvɝ æskt, iðɝ. ðə bɔldɪŋ mæn lʊkt ət ɹændz sɔɹd, tu, ən pɝst ɪz lɪps fəɹ ən ɪnstənt.

Tavolin came out, trailing another officer and two clerks, one carrying a large, wood-bound ledger and the other a tray with writing implements. The front of the officer's head was shaven like Tavolin's, though advancing baldness seemed to have taken more hair than the razor. Both officers looked from Rand to the chest hidden by Loial's striped blanket and back again. Neither asked what was under the blanket. Tavolin had looked at it often on the way from Tremonsien, but he had never asked, either. The balding man looked at Rand's sword, too, and pursed his lips for an instant.

tɑvəlɪn ɡeɪv ði ʌðɝ ɔfəsɝz neɪm əz ɑsən sændɛɹ, ən ənaʊns laʊdli, "lɔɹd ɹænd ə haʊs ælθɹ, ɪn ændɝ, ən ɪz mæn, kɔl hʊɹɪn, wɪð lɔɪəl, ən oʊɡiɝ ə stɛɾɪŋ ʃæŋktaɪ." ðə klɝk wɪð ðə lɛdʒɝ oʊpən ɪɾ əkɹɔs ɪz tu ɑɹmz, ən sændɛɹ ɹoʊt ðə neɪmz ɪn ə ɹaʊn hænd.

Tavolin gave the other officer's name as Asan Sandair, and announced loudly, "Lord Rand of House al'Thor, in Andor, and his man, called Hurin, with Loial, an Ogier of Stedding Shangtai." The clerk with the ledger opened it across his two arms, and Sandair wrote the names in a round hand.

"ju mʌst ɹɪtɝn tə ðɪs ɡɑɹdhaʊs baɪ ðɪs seɪm aʊɝ təmɑɹoʊ, maɪ lɔɹd," sændɛɹ sɛd, livɪŋ ðə sændɪŋ tə ðə sɛkən klɝk, "ænd ɡɪv ðə neɪm ə ði ɪn wɛɹ jə ɑɹ steɪɪŋ."

"You must return to this guardhouse by this same hour tomorrow, my Lord," Sandair said, leaving the sanding to the second clerk, "and give the name of the inn where you are staying."

ɹænd lʊkt ət ðə steɪd stʃɹits ə kɛɹhin, ðən bæk ət ðə laɪvlinəs ə ðə fɔɹɡeɪt. "kæn jə tɛl mi ðə neɪm ʌv ə ɡʊɾ ɪn aʊt ðɛɹ?" hi nɑɾəd tə ðə fɔɹɡeɪt.

Rand looked at the staid streets of Cairhien, then back at the liveliness of the Foregate. "Can you tell me the name of a good inn out there?" He nodded to the Foregate.

hʊɹɪn meɪɾ ə fɹæntɪk st ən lin kloʊs. "ɪt wəd nɑt bi pɹɑpɝ, lɔɹd ɹænd," hi wɪspɝd. "ɪf jə steɪ ɪn ðə fɔɹɡeɪt, biɪŋ ə lɔɹɾ ən ɔl, ðəl bi ʃʊɹ jə ɑɹ ʌp tə sʌmθɪŋ."

Hurin made a frantic hsst and leaned close. "It would not be proper, Lord Rand," he whispered. "If you stay in the Foregate, being a lord and all, they'll be sure you are up to something."

ɹænd kəd si ðə snɪfɝ wɑz ɹaɪt. sændɛɹz maʊθ hæd dʒɹɑpt oʊpən ən tɑvəlɪnz bɹaʊz hæd ɹɪzən əɾ ɪz kwɛstʃən, ən ðeɪ wɝ boʊθ stɪl wɑtʃɪŋ ɪm ɪntɛnli. hi wɑntəd tə tɛl əm i wɑz nɑt pleɪɪŋ ðɛɹ ɡɹeɪt ɡeɪm, bʌɾ ɪnstɛɾ i sɛd, "wi wɪl teɪk ɹumz ɪn ðə sɪɾi. wi kən ɡoʊ naʊ?"

Rand could see the sniffer was right. Sandair's mouth had dropped open and Tavolin's brows had risen at his question, and they were both still watching him intently. He wanted to tell them he was not playing their Great Game, but instead he said, "We will take rooms in the city. We can go now?"

"ʌv kɔɹs, maɪ lɔɹd ɹænd." sændɛɹ meɪɾ ə baʊ. "bʌt . . . ði ɪn?"

"Of course, my Lord Rand." Sandair made a bow. "But . . . the inn?"

"aɪ wɪl lɛt jə noʊ wən wi faɪnd wʌn." ɹænd tɝn ɹɛd, ðən pɔzd. səlinz noʊt kɹækəld ɪn ɪz pɑkət. "aɪ nid tə faɪn ə jʌŋ wʊmən fɹəm kɛɹhin. ðə leɪɾi səlin. ʃiz maɪ eɪdʒ, ən bjuɾəfəl. aɪ doʊnt noʊ hɝ haʊs."

"I will let you know when we find one." Rand turned Red, then paused. Selene's note crackled in his pocket. "I need to find a young woman from Cairhien. The Lady Selene. She is my age, and beautiful. I don't know her House."

sændɛɹ ən tɑvəlɪn ɪkstʃeɪnʒd lʊks, ðən sændɛɹ sɛd, "aɪ wɪl meɪk ɪnkwaɪɝiz, maɪ lɔɹd. pɝhæps əl bi eɪbəl tə tɛl jə sʌmθɪŋ wən jə kʌm təmɑɹoʊ."

Sandair and Tavolin exchanged looks, then Sandair said, "I will make inquiries, my Lord. Perhaps I will be able to tell you something when you come tomorrow."

ɹænd nɑɾəd ən lɛd lɔɪəl ən hʊɹɪn ɪndə ðə sɪɾi. ðeɪ ətʃɹæktəd lɪɾəl noʊɾəs, ðoʊ ðəɹ wɝ fju ɹaɪɾɝz. ivən lɔɪəl ətʃɹæktəɾ ɔlmoʊs nʌn. ðə pipəl sim nɪɹli ɑstənteɪʃəs əbaʊt maɪndɪŋ ðɛɹ oʊn bɪznəs.

Rand nodded and led Loial and Hurin into the city. They attracted little notice, though there were few riders. Even Loial attracted almost none. The people seemed nearly ostentatious about minding their own business.

"wɪl ðeɪ teɪk ɪt ðə ɹɔŋ weɪ," ɹænd æsk hʊɹɪn, "maɪ æskɪŋ æftɝ səlin?"

"Will they take it the wrong way," Rand asked Hurin, "my asking after Selene?"

"hu kən seɪ wɪð kɛɹhinɪn, lɔɹd ɹænd? ðeɪ sim tə θɪŋk ɛvɹiθɪŋ əz tə də wɪð deɪz deɪmɑɹ."

"Who can say with Cairhienin, Lord Rand? They seem to think everything has to do with Daes Dae'mar."

ɹænd ʃɹʌɡd. hi fɛlt əz ɪf pipəl wɝ lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm. hi kəd nɑt weɪt tə ɡɛɾ ə ɡʊd, pleɪn koʊɾ əɡɛn, ən stɑp pɹitɛndɪŋ tə bi wʌɾ i wɑz nɑt.

Rand shrugged. He felt as if people were looking at him. He could not wait to get a good, plain coat again, and stop pretending to be what he was not.

hʊɹɪn nu sɛvɹəl ɪnz ɪn ðə sɪɾi, ðoʊ hɪz taɪm ɪn kɛɹhin hæd bɪn spɛn meɪnli ɪn ðə fɔɹɡeɪt. ðə snɪfɝ lɛɾ əm tə wʌn kɔl ðə dɪfɛndɝ ə ðə dʒɹæɡoʊnwɔl, ðə saɪn bɛɹɪŋ ə kɹaʊn mæn wɪð ɪz fʊɾ ɑn ənʌðɝ mænz tʃɛst ən ɪz sɔɹɾ ət ðə mænz θɹoʊt. ðə fɛloʊ ɑn ɪz bæk hæd ɹɛd hɛɹ.

Hurin knew several inns in the city, though his time in Cairhien had been spent mainly in the Foregate. The sniffer led them to one called The Defender of the Dragonwall, the sign bearing a crowned man with his foot on another man's chest and his sword at the man's throat. The fellow on his back had red hair.

ə hɑslɝ keɪm tə teɪk ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz, dɑɹɾɪŋ kwɪk lʊks ət ɹænd ən ət lɔɪəl wən i θɔɾ i wɑz nɑɾ əbzɝvd. ɹænd toʊl hɪmsɛlf tə stɑp hævɪŋ fænsiz; nɑɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn ðə sɪɾi kəd bi pleɪɪŋ ðɪs ɡeɪm ə ðɛɹz. ən ɪf ðeɪ wɝ, hi wɑz noʊ pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt.

A hostler came to take their horses, darting quick looks at Rand and at Loial when he thought he was not observed. Rand told himself to stop having fancies; not everyone in the city could be playing this Game of theirs. And if they were, he was no part of it.

ðə kɑmən ɹum wɑz nit, wɪð ðə teɪbəlz leɪɾ aʊɾ əz stʃɹɪkli əz ðə sɪɾi, ən oʊnli ə fju pipəl ət ðɛm. ðeɪ ɡlænst ʌp ət ðə nukʌmɝz, ðən bæk tə ðɛɹ waɪn ɪmiɾiətli; ɹænd hæd ðə filɪŋ ðeɪ wɝ stɪl wɑtʃɪŋ, ðoʊ, ən lɪsnɪŋ. ə smɔl faɪɝ bɝn ɪn ðə bɪɡ faɪɝpleɪs, ðoʊ ðə deɪ wɑz wɔɹmɪŋ.

The common room was neat, with the tables laid out as strictly as the city, and only a few people at them. They glanced up at the newcomers, then back to their wine immediately; Rand had the feeling they were still watching, though, and listening. A small fire burned in the big fireplace, though the day was warming.

ði ɪnkipɝ wɑz ə plʌmp, ʌŋtʃwəs mæn wɪð ə sɪŋɡəl stʃɹaɪp ʌv ɡɹin əkɹɔs ɪz dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ koʊt. hi ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ əɾ ɪz fɝst saɪɾ ə ðɛm, ən ɹænd wɑz nɑt sɝpɹaɪzd. lɔɪəl, wɪð ðə tʃɛst ɪn ɪz ɑɹmz ʌndɝ ɪts stʃɹaɪp blæŋkət, hæd tə dʌk ɪz hɛd tə meɪk ɪɾ ɪn θɹu ðə dɔɹ, hʊɹɪn wɑz bɝɾənd wɪð ɔl ðɛɹ sæɾəlbæɡz ən bʌndəlz, ən ɪz oʊn ɹɛd koʊt wɑz ə ʃɑɹp kɑntʃɹæs tə ðə sɑmbɝ kʌlɝz ðə pipəl ət ðə teɪbəlz wɔɹ.

The innkeeper was a plump, unctuous man with a single stripe of green across his dark gray coat. He gave a start at his first sight of them, and Rand was not surprised. Loial, with the chest in his arms under its striped blanket, had to duck his head to make it in through the door, Hurin was burdened with all their saddlebags and bundles, and his own red coat was a sharp contrast to the somber colors the people at the tables wore.

ði ɪnkipɝ tʊk ɪn ɹændz koʊɾ ən ɪz sɔɹd, ən ɪz ɔɪli smaɪl keɪm bæk. hi baʊd, wɑʃɪŋ ɪz smuð hænz. "fɝɡɪv mi, maɪ lɔɹd. ɪt wɑz dʒʌs ðət fəɹ ə moʊmən aɪ tʊk jə fəɹ - fɝɡɪv mi. maɪ bɹeɪn ɪz nɑt wʌɾ ɪt wɑz. jə wɪʃ ɹumz, maɪ lɔɹd?" hi æɾəd ənʌðɝ, lɛsɝ baʊ fəɹ lɔɪəl. "aɪ æm kɔl kueɪli, maɪ lɔɹd."

The innkeeper took in Rand's coat and his sword, and his oily smile came back. He bowed, washing his smooth hands. "Forgive me, my Lord. It was just that for a moment I took you for - Forgive me. My brain is not what it was. You wish rooms, my Lord?" He added another, lesser bow for Loial. "I am called Cuale, my Lord."

hi θɔɾ aɪ wɑz il, ɹænd θɔt saʊɝli. hi wɑntəd tə bi ɡɔn fɹəm kɛɹhin. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðə wʌn pleɪs ɪŋtʃɹ maɪt faɪn ðɛm. ən səlin hæd sɛd ʃi wəd weɪt fəɹ ɪm ɪn kɛɹhin.

He thought I was Aiel, Rand thought sourly. He wanted to be gone from Cairhien. But it was the one place Ingtar might find them. And Selene had said she would wait for him in Cairhien.

ɪt tʊk ə lɪɾəl taɪm fəɹ ðɛɹ ɹumz tə bi ɹɛɾid, kueɪli ɪkspleɪnɪŋ wɪð tu mɛni smaɪlz ən baʊz ðəɾ ɪt wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi tə muv ə bɛd fəɹ lɔɪəl. ɹænd wɑntəɾ əm ɔl tə ʃɛɹ ə ɹum əɡɛn, bʌt bɪtwin ði ɪnkipɝz skændəlaɪz lʊks ən hʊɹɪnz ɪnsɪstəns - "wi hæv tə ʃoʊ ðiz kɛɹhinɪn wi noʊ wʌts ɹaɪɾ əz wɛl əz ðeɪ du, lɔɹd ɹænd" - ðeɪ ɛndəd wɪð tu, wʌn fəɹ ɪm əloʊn, wɪð ə kənɛktɪŋ dɔɹ.

It took a little time for their rooms to be readied, Cuale explaining with too many smiles and bows that it was necessary to move a bed for Loial. Rand wanted them all to share a room again, but between the innkeeper's scandalized looks and Hurin's insistence - "We have to show these Cairhienin we know what's right as well as they do, Lord Rand" - they ended with two, one for him alone, with a connecting door.

ðə ɹumz wɝ mʌtʃ ðə seɪm ɪksɛp ðət ðɛɹz hæd tu bɛdz, wʌn saɪz fəɹ ən oʊɡiɝ, waɪl ɪz hæɾ oʊnli wʌn bɛd, ən ðəɾ ɔlmoʊst əz bɪɡ əz ði ʌðɝ tu, wɪð mæsɪv skwɛɹ poʊsts ðət nɪɹli ɹitʃt ðə silɪŋ. hɪz tɔl-bækt, pæɾəd tʃɛɹ ən ðə wɑʃstænd wɝ skwɛɹ ən mæsɪv, tu, ən ðə wɔɹdʒɹoʊb stændɪŋ əɡɛnst ɪz wɔl wɑz kɑɹvd ɪn ə hɛvi, ɹɪdʒəd staɪl ðət meɪd ðə θɪŋ lʊk ɹɛɾi ɪnʌf tə fɔl oʊvɝ ɑn hɪm. ə pɛɹ ʌv wɪndoʊz saɪɾɪŋ ɪz bɛd lʊkt aʊɾ ɑn ðə stʃɹit, tu flɔɹz bɪloʊ.

The rooms were much the same except that theirs had two beds, one sized for an Ogier, while his had only one bed, and that almost as big as the other two, with massive square posts that nearly reached the ceiling. His tall-backed, padded chair and the washstand were square and massive, too, and the wardrobe standing against his wall was carved in a heavy, rigid style that made the thing look ready enough to fall over on him. A pair of windows siding his bed looked out on the street, two floors below.

əz sun əz ði ɪnkipɝ lɛft, ɹænd oʊpən ðə dɔɹ ən ədmɪɾəd lɔɪəl ən hʊɹɪn ɪndə hɪz ɹum. "ðɪs pleɪs nɔz ət mi," hi toʊl ðɛm. "ɛvɹibɑɾi lʊks ət jə əz ɪf ðeɪ θɪŋk jəɹ duɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ. aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ bæk tə ðə fɔɹɡeɪt, fəɹ ən aʊɝ ɛniweɪ. ət lis ðə pipəl læf, ðɛɹ. wɪtʃ ə jə ɪz wɪlɪŋ tə teɪk ðə fɝst wɑtʃ ɑn ðə hɔɹn?"

As soon as the innkeeper left, Rand opened the door and admitted Loial and Hurin into his room. "This place gnaws at me," he told them. "Everybody looks at you as if they think you're doing something. I'm going back to the Foregate, for an hour anyway. At least the people laugh, there. Which of you is willing to take the first watch on the Horn?"

"aɪ wɪl steɪ," lɔɪəl sɛd kwɪkli. "aɪd laɪk ə tʃæns tə də ə lɪɾəl ɹɛɾɪŋ. dʒʌs kəz aɪ dɪdn si ɛni oʊɡiɝ dʌz nɑt min ðəɹ ɑɹ noʊ stoʊnmeɪsɑnz daʊn fɹəm stɛɾɪŋ tsəfu. ɪts nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm ðə sɪɾi."

"I will stay," Loial said quickly. "I'd like a chance to do a little reading. Just because I didn't see any Ogier does not mean there are no stonemasons down from Stedding Tsofu. It is not far from the city."

"aɪd θɪŋk jə wəd wɑnə mit ðɛm."

"I'd think you would want to meet them."

"ɑ . . . noʊ, ɹænd. ðeɪ æskt ɪnʌf kwɛstʃənz ðə læs taɪm əbaʊt waɪ aɪ wɑz aʊtsaɪɾ əloʊn əz ɪt wɑz. ɪf ðeɪv hæd wɝd fɹəm stɛɾɪŋ ʃæŋktaɪ. . . . wɛl, əl dʒʌst ɹɛs hɪɹ ən ɹɛd, aɪ θɪŋk."

"Ah . . . no, Rand. They asked enough questions the last time about why I was outside alone as it was. If they've had word from Stedding Shangtai. . . . Well, I will just rest here and read, I think."

ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. hi ɔfən fɝɡɑt ðət lɔɪəl hæd ɹʌn əweɪ fɹəm hoʊm, ɪn ɪfɛkt, tə si ðə wɝld. "wʌɾ əbaʊt ju, hʊɹɪn? ðɛɹz mjuzɪk ɪn ðə fɔɹɡeɪt, ən pipəl læfɪŋ. əl weɪdʒɝ noʊ wʌn ɪz pleɪɪŋ deɪz deɪmɑɹ ðɛɹ."

Rand shook his head. He often forgot that Loial had run away from home, in effect, to see the world. "What about you, Hurin? There's music in the Foregate, and people laughing. I'll wager no one is playing Daes Dae'mar there."

"aɪ wəd nɑt bi soʊ sɝɾən ə ðət maɪsɛlf, lɔɹd ɹænd. ɪn ɛni keɪs, aɪ θæŋk jə fəɹ ði ɪnvɪteɪʃən, bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk nɑt. ðɛɹz soʊ mɛni faɪts - ən kɪlɪŋz, tu - ɪn fɔɹɡeɪt, ðəɾ ɪt stɪŋks, ɪf jə noʊ wʌɾ aɪ min. nɑt ðət ðəɹ laɪkli tə bɑðɝ ə lɔɹd, ʌv kɔɹs; ðə soʊlʒɝz wəd bi daʊn ɑn əm ɪf ðeɪ dɪd. bʌɾ ɪf ɪt plizɪz ju, aɪ wəd laɪk tə hæv ə dʒɹɪŋk ɪn ðə kɑmən ɹum."

"I would not be so certain of that myself, Lord Rand. In any case, I thank you for the invitation, but I think not. There's so many fights - and killings, too - in Foregate, that it stinks, if you know what I mean. Not that they're likely to bother a lord, of course; the soldiers would be down on them if they did. But if it pleases you, I would like to have a drink in the common room."

"hʊɹɪn, jə doʊnt nid maɪ pɝmɪʃən fəɹ ɛniθɪŋ. jə noʊ ðæt."

"Hurin, you don't need my permission for anything. You know that."

"æz jə seɪ, maɪ lɔɹd." ðə snɪfɝ ɡeɪv ə sədʒɛstʃən ʌv ə baʊ.

"As you say, my Lord." The sniffer gave a suggestion of a bow.

ɹænd tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. ɪf ðeɪ dɪd nɑt liv kɛɹhin sun, hʊɹɪn wəd bi boʊɪŋ ən skɹeɪpɪŋ lɛft ən ɹaɪt. ən ɪf mæt ən pɛɹɪn sɔ ðæt, ðeɪ wəd nɛvɝ lɛɾ ɪm fɝɡɛɾ ɪt. "aɪ hoʊp nʌθɪŋ dɪleɪz ɪŋtʃɹ. ɪf i dʌzn kʌm kwɪkli, wɪl əv tə teɪk ðə hɔɹn bæk tə fæl dæɹə aʊɝsɛlvz." hi tʌtʃt səlinz noʊt θɹu hɪz koʊt. "wi wɪl əv tə. lɔɪəl, əl kʌm bæk soʊ jə kən si səm ə ðə sɪɾi."

Rand took a deep breath. If they did not leave Cairhien soon, Hurin would be bowing and scraping left and right. And if Mat and Perrin saw that, they would never let him forget it. "I hope nothing delays Ingtar. If he doesn't come quickly, we'll have to take the Horn back to Fal Dara ourselves." He touched Selene's note through his coat. "We will have to. Loial, I'll come back so you can see some of the city."

"aɪd ɹæðɝ nɑt ɹɪsk ɪt," lɔɪəl sɛd.

"I'd rather not risk it," Loial said.

hʊɹɪn əkʌmpənid ɹænd daʊnstɛɹz. əz sun əz ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə kɑmən ɹum, kueɪli wɑz boʊɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə ɹænd, pʊʃɪŋ ə tʃɹeɪ ət hɪm. θɹi foʊldəɾ ən sil pɑɹtʃməns leɪ ɑn ðə tʃɹeɪ. ɹænd tʊk ðɛm, sɪns ðət wɑz wʌt ði ɪnkipɝ sim tə ɪntɛnd. ðeɪ wɝ ə faɪn ɡɹeɪɾ ə pɑɹtʃmənt, sɑft ən smuð tə hɪz tʌtʃ. ɪkspɛnsɪv.

Hurin accompanied Rand downstairs. As soon as they reached the common room, Cuale was bowing in front of Rand, pushing a tray at him. Three folded and sealed parchments lay on the tray. Rand took them, since that was what the innkeeper seemed to intend. They were a fine grade of parchment, soft and smooth to his touch. Expensive.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ ðiz?" hi æskt.

"What are these?" he asked.

kueɪli baʊɾ əɡɛn. "ɪnvɪteɪʃənz, ʌv kɔɹs, maɪ lɔɹd. fɹəm θɹi ʌv ðə noʊbəl haʊsəz." hi baʊd hɪmsɛlf əweɪ.

Cuale bowed again. "Invitations, of course, my Lord. From three of the noble Houses." He bowed himself away.

"hu wəd sɛn mi ɪnvɪteɪʃənz?" ɹænd tɝn əm oʊvɝ ɪn ɪz hænd. nʌn ə ðə mɛn ət ðə teɪbəlz lʊkt ʌp, bʌɾ i hæd ðə filɪŋ ðeɪ wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ dʒʌs ðə seɪm. hi dɪd nɑt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə silz. nʌn wɑz ðə kɹɛsən mun ən stɑɹz səlin hæd juzd. "hu wəd noʊ aɪ wɑz hɪɹ?"

"Who would send me invitations?" Rand turned them over in his hand. None of the men at the tables looked up, but he had the feeling they were watching just the same. He did not recognize the seals. None was the crescent moon and stars Selene had used. "Who would know I was here?"

"ɛvɹiwʌn baɪ naʊ, lɔɹd ɹænd," hʊɹɪn sɛd kwaɪətli. hi sim tə fil aɪz wɑtʃɪŋ, tu. "ðə ɡɑɹdz ət ðə ɡeɪt wəd nɑt kip ðɛɹ maʊðz kloʊzd əbaʊɾ ən aʊtlæn lɔɹd kʌmɪŋ tə kɛɹhin. ðə hɑslɝ, ði ɪnkipɝ . . . ɛvɹibɑɾi tɛlz wʌt ðeɪ noʊ wɛɹ ðeɪ θɪŋk ɪɾəl də ðɛm ðə moʊst ɡʊd, maɪ lɔɹd."

"Everyone by now, Lord Rand," Hurin said quietly. He seemed to feel eyes watching, too. "The guards at the gate would not keep their mouths closed about an outland lord coming to Cairhien. The hostler, the innkeeper . . . everybody tells what they know where they think it will do them the most good, my Lord."

wɪð ə ɡɹɪmɑs, ɹænd tʊk tu stɛps ən hɝl ði ɪnvɪteɪʃənz ɪndə ðə faɪɝ. ðeɪ kɑɾ ɪmiɾiətli. "aɪ æm nɑt pleɪɪŋ deɪz deɪmɑɹ," hi sɛd, laʊdli ɪnʌf fəɹ ɛvɹiwʌn tə hɪɹ. nɑɾ ivən kueɪli lʊkt ət hɪm. "aɪv nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð jəɹ ɡɹeɪt ɡeɪm. aɪm dʒʌs hɪɹ tə weɪt fəɹ səm fɹɛnz."

With a grimace, Rand took two steps and hurled the invitations into the fire. They caught immediately. "I am not playing Daes Dae'mar," he said, loudly enough for everyone to hear. Not even Cuale looked at him. "I've nothing to do with your Great Game. I am just here to wait for some friends."

hʊɹɪn kɑɾ ɪz ɑɹm. "pliz, lɔɹd ɹænd." hɪz vɔɪs wɑz ən ɝdʒənt wɪspɝ. "pliz doʊn də ðəɾ əɡɛn."

Hurin caught his arm. "Please, Lord Rand." His voice was an urgent whisper. "Please don't do that again."

"əɡɛn? jə ɹɪli θɪŋk əl ɹəsiv mɔɹ?"

"Again? You really think I'll receive more?"

"aɪm sɝɾən. laɪt, bʌt jə maɪn mi ʌv ðə taɪm teɪvə ɡɑt soʊ mæɾ əɾ ə hɔɹnɪt bʌzɪŋ ɹaʊn ɪz ɪɹz, hi kɪk ðə nɛst. juv laɪkli dʒʌs kənvɪnst ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn ðə ɹum jə ɑɹ ɪn səm dip pɑɹɾ ə ðə ɡeɪm. ɪt mʌs bi dip, əz ðəl si ɪt, ɪf jə dɪnaɪ pleɪɪŋ əɾ ɔl. ɛvɹi lɔɹɾ ən leɪɾi ɪn kɛɹhin pleɪz ɪt." ðə snɪfɝ ɡlænst ət ði ɪnvɪteɪʃənz, kɝlɪŋ blækli ɪn ðə faɪɝ, ən wɪnst. "æn juv ʃʊɹli meɪɾ ɛnəmiz ə θɹi haʊsəz. nɑt ɡɹeɪt haʊsəz, əɹ ðeɪd nɑɾ əv muv soʊ kwɪkli, bʌt stɪl noʊbəl. jə mʌst ænsɝ ɛni mɔɹ ɪnvɪteɪʃənz jə ɹəsiv, maɪ lɔɹd. dɪklaɪn ɪf jəl - ðoʊ ðəl ɹɛd θɪŋz ɪndə huz ɪnvɪteɪʃənz jə də dɪklaɪn. ən ɪndə huz jə æksɛpt. ʌv kɔɹs, ɪf jə dɪklaɪn əm ɔl, əɹ æksɛpt əm ɔl - "

"I'm certain. Light, but you mind me of the time Teva got so mad at a hornet buzzing round his ears, he kicked the nest. You've likely just convinced everyone in the room you are in some deep part of the Game. It must be deep, as they'll see it, if you deny playing at all. Every lord and lady in Cairhien plays it." The sniffer glanced at the invitations, curling blackly in the fire, and winced. "And you have surely made enemies of three Houses. Not great Houses, or they'd not have moved so quickly, but still noble. You must answer any more invitations you receive, my Lord. Decline if you will - though they'll read things into whose invitations you do decline. And into whose you accept. Of course, if you decline them all, or accept them all - "

"aɪl əv noʊ pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt," ɹænd sɛd kwaɪətli. "wi ɑɹ livɪŋ kɛɹhin əz sun əz wi kæn." hi θɹʌst ɪz fɪsts ɪndə hɪz koʊt pɑkəts, ən fɛl səlinz noʊt kɹʌmpəl. pʊlɪŋ ɪɾ aʊt, hi smuðd ɪɾ ɑn ɪz koʊt fɹʌnt. "æz sun əz wi kæn," hi mʌɾɝd, pʊɾɪŋ ɪt bæk ɪn ɪz pɑkəɾ əɡɛn. "hæv jəɹ dʒɹɪŋk, hʊɹɪn."

"I'll have no part of it," Rand said quietly. "We are leaving Cairhien as soon as we can." He thrust his fists into his coat pockets, and felt Selene's note crumple. Pulling it out, he smoothed it on his coat front. "As soon as we can," he muttered, putting it back in his pocket again. "Have your drink, Hurin."

hi stɔkt aʊɾ æŋɡɹəli, nɑt ʃʊɹ wɛðɝ i wɑz æŋɡɹi wɪð hɪmsɛlf, əɹ wɪð kɛɹhin ən ɪts ɡɹeɪt ɡeɪm, əɹ səlin fəɹ vænɪʃɪŋ, əɹ mɔɪɹeɪn. ʃi hæd stɑɹɾəd ɪɾ ɔl, stilɪŋ ɪz koʊts ən ɡɪvɪŋ ɪm ə lɔɹdz kloʊðz ɪnstɛd. ivən naʊ ðəɾ i kɔl hɪmsɛlf fɹi ʌv ðɛm, ən ɛɛs sədaɪ stɪl mænədʒ tə ɪntɝfɪɹ ɪn ɪz laɪf, ən wɪθaʊɾ ivən biɪŋ ðɛɹ.

He stalked out angrily, not sure whether he was angry with himself, or with Cairhien and its Great Game, or Selene for vanishing, or Moiraine. She had started it all, stealing his coats and giving him a lord's clothes instead. Even now that he called himself free of them, an Aes Sedai still managed to interfere in his life, and without even being there.

hi wɛn bæk θɹu ðə seɪm ɡeɪt baɪ wɪtʃ i hæɾ ɛntɝd ðə sɪɾi, sɪns ðət wɑz ðə weɪ hi nu. ə mæn stændɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə ɡɑɹdhaʊs tʊk noʊɾ ə hɪm - hɪz bɹaɪt koʊt mɑɹkt ɪm aʊt, əz wɛl əz ɪz haɪɾ əmʌŋ ðə kɛɹhinɪn - ən hɝiɾ ɪnsaɪd, bʌt ɹænd dɪd nɑt noʊɾəs. ðə læftɝ ən mjuzɪk ə ðə fɔɹɡeɪt wɝ pʊlɪŋ ɪm ɑn.

He went back through the same gate by which he had entered the city, since that was the way he knew. A man standing in front of the guardhouse took note of him - his bright coat marked him out, as well as his height among the Cairhienin - and hurried inside, but Rand did not notice. The laughter and music of the Foregate were pulling him on.

ɪf ɪz ɡoʊld-ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɹɛd koʊt meɪɾ ɪm stæn aʊɾ ɪnsaɪd ðə wɔlz, ɪt fɪt ɹaɪɾ ɪndə ðə fɔɹɡeɪt. mɛni ʌv ðə mɛn mɪlɪŋ θɹu ðə kɹaʊɾəd stʃɹits wɝ dʒɹɛs dʒʌst əz dɑɹkli əz ðoʊz ɪn ðə sɪɾi, bʌt dʒʌst əz mɛni wɔɹ koʊts ə ɹɛd, əɹ blu, əɹ ɡɹin, əɹ ɡoʊld - səm bɹaɪɾ ɪnʌf tə bi ə tɪŋkɝz kloʊðz - ən ivən mɔɹ ə ðə wɪmən hæɾ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd dʒɹɛsəz ən kʌlɝd skɑɹvz əɹ ʃɔlz. moʊst ə ðə faɪnɝi wɑz tæɾɝd ən ɪl-fɪɾɪŋ, əz ɪf meɪd fəɹ sʌmwʌn ɛls ɝɪdʒənəli, bʌɾ ɪf səm ə ðoʊz u wɔɹ ɪɾ aɪɾ ɪz faɪn koʊt, nʌn sim tə teɪk ɪɾ əmɪs.

If his gold-embroidered red coat made him stand out inside the walls, it fit right into the Foregate. Many of the men milling through the crowded streets were dressed just as darkly as those in the city, but just as many wore coats of red, or blue, or green, or gold - some bright enough to be a Tinker's clothes - and even more of the women had embroidered dresses and colored scarves or shawls. Most of the finery was tattered and ill-fitting, as if made for someone else originally, but if some of those who wore it eyed his fine coat, none seemed to take it amiss.

wʌns i hæd tə stɑp fəɹ ənʌðɝ pɹəsɛʃən ə dʒaɪən pʌpəts. waɪl ðə dʒɹʌmɝz bit ðɛɹ tæmbɔɝz ən keɪpɝd, ə pɪɡ-feɪs tʃɹɑlɑk wɪð tʌsks fɔɾ ə mæn ɪn ə kɹaʊn. æftɝ ə fju dɛsəltɔɹi bloʊz, ðə tʃɹɑlɑk kəlæps tə læftɝ ən tʃɪɹz fɹəm ði ɔnlʊkɝz.

Once he had to stop for another procession of giant puppets. While the drummers beat their tambours and capered, a pig-faced Trolloc with tusks fought a man in a crown. After a few desultory blows, the Trolloc collapsed to laughter and cheers from the onlookers.

ɹænd ɡɹʌntɪd. ðeɪ doʊn daɪ soʊ izəli əz ðæt.

Rand grunted. They don't die so easily as that.

hi ɡlænst ɪndə wʌn ə ðə lɑɹdʒ, wɪndoʊləs bɪldɪŋz, stɑpɪŋ tə lʊk θɹu ðə dɔɹ. tə hɪz sɝpɹaɪz, ɪt sim tə bi wʌn hjudʒ ɹum, oʊpən tə ðə skaɪ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ən laɪnd wɪð bælkəniz, wɪð ə lɑɹdʒ deɪz ət wʌn ɛnd. hi hæd nɛvɝ sin əɹ hɝɾ ʌv ɛniθɪŋ laɪk ɪt. pipəl dʒæm ðə bælkəniz ən ðə flɔɹ wɑtʃɪŋ pipəl pɝfɔɹm ɑn ðə deɪz. hi pikt ɪndə ʌðɝz əz i pæs ðɛm, ən sɔ dʒʌɡəlɝz, ən mjuzɪʃənz, ɛni nʌmbɝ ə tʌmblɝz, ən ivən ə ɡlimən, wɪð ɪz kloʊk ə pætʃəz, dɪkleɪmɪŋ ə stɔɹi fɹəm ðə ɡɹeɪt hʌn ə ðə hɔɹn ɪn sɑnɝəs-vɔɪs haɪ tʃænt.

He glanced into one of the large, windowless buildings, stopping to look through the door. To his surprise, it seemed to be one huge room, open to the sky in the middle and lined with balconies, with a large dais at one end. He had never seen or heard of anything like it. People jammed the balconies and the floor watching people perform on the dais. He peeked into others as he passed them, and saw jugglers, and musicians, any number of tumblers, and even a gleeman, with his cloak of patches, declaiming a story from The Great Hunt of the Horn in sonorous-voice High Chant.

ðət meɪɾ ɪm θɪŋk ə tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn, ən i hɝiɾ ɑn. mɛmɹiz ə tɑm wɝ ɔlweɪz sæd. tɑm hæd bɪn ə fɹɛnd. ə fɹɛn u hæd daɪd fəɹ hɪm. waɪl aɪ ɹæn əweɪ ən lɛɾ ɪm daɪ.

That made him think of Thom Merrilin, and he hurried on. Memories of Thom were always sad. Thom had been a friend. A friend who had died for him. While I ran away and let him die.

ɪn ənʌðɝ ə ðə bɪɡ stʃɹʌktʃɝz, ə wʊmən ɪn vəlumənəs waɪt ɹoʊbz əpɪɹd tə meɪk θɪŋz vænɪʃ fɹəm wʌn bæskəɾ ən əpɪɹ ɪn ənʌðɝ, ðən dɪsəpɪɹ fɹəm əɹ hænz ɪn ɡɹeɪt pʌfs ə smoʊk. ðə kɹaʊd wɑtʃɪŋ əɹ uɾ ən eɪh laʊdli.

In another of the big structures, a woman in voluminous white robes appeared to make things vanish from one basket and appear in another, then disappear from her hands in great puffs of smoke. The crowd watching her oohed and aahed loudly.

"tu kɑpɝz, maɪ ɡʊd lɔɹd," ə ɹæɾi lɪɾəl mæn ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ sɛd. "tu kɑpɝz tə si ði ɛɛs sədaɪ."

"Two coppers, my good Lord," a ratty little man in the doorway said. "Two coppers to see the Aes Sedai."

"aɪ doʊn θɪŋk soʊ." ɹænd ɡlæns bæk ət ðə wʊmən. ə waɪt dʌv hæɾ əpɪɹɾ ɪn əɹ hænz. ɛɛs sədaɪ? "noʊ." hi ɡeɪv ðə ɹæɾi mæn ə smɔl baʊ ən lɛft.

"I don't think so." Rand glanced back at the woman. A white dove had appeared in her hands. Aes Sedai? "No." He gave the ratty man a small bow and left.

hi wɑz meɪkɪŋ ɪz weɪ θɹu ðə θɹɔŋ, wʌndɝɪŋ wʌt tə si nɛkst, wən ə dip vɔɪs, əkʌmpənid baɪ ðə plʌkɪŋ ʌv ə hɑɹp, dʒɹɪftəɾ aʊt fɹəm ə dɔɹweɪ wɪð ðə saɪn ʌv ə dʒʌɡəlɝ oʊvɝ ɪt.

He was making his way through the throng, wondering what to see next, when a deep voice, accompanied by the plucking of a harp, drifted out from a doorway with the sign of a juggler over it.

". . . koʊl bloʊz ðə wɪn daʊn ʃɑɹə pæs; koʊld laɪz ðə ɡɹeɪv ənmɑɹkt. jɛɾ ɛvɹi jɪɹ ət sʌndeɪ, əpɑn ðoʊz paɪl stoʊnz əpɪɹz ə sɪŋɡəl ɹoʊz, wʌn kɹɪstəl tɪɹdʒɹɑp laɪk du əpɑn ðə pɛɾəlz, leɪd baɪ ðə fɛɹ hæn ə dʌnsaɪnɪn, fəɹ ʃi kips fæs tə ðə bɑɹɡən meɪd baɪ ɹəɡoʊʃ iɡəl-aɪ."

". . . cold blows the wind down Shara Pass; cold lies the grave unmarked. Yet every year at Sunday, upon those piled stones appears a single rose, one crystal teardrop like dew upon the petals, laid by the fair hand of Dunsinin, for she keeps fast to the bargain made by Rogosh Eagle-eye."

ðə vɔɪs dʒɹu ɹænd laɪk ə ɹoʊp. hi pʊʃt θɹu ðə dɔɹweɪ əz əplɔz ɹoʊz wɪðɪn.

The voice drew Rand like a rope. He pushed through the doorway as applause rose within.

"tu kɑpɝz, maɪ ɡʊd lɔɹd," sɛɾ ə ɹæt-feɪs mæn u cʊɾə bɪn twɪn tə ði ʌðɝ. "tu kɑpɝz tə si - "

"Two coppers, my good Lord," said a rat-faced man who could have been twin to the other. "Two coppers to see - "

ɹænd dʌɡ aʊt səm kɔɪnz ən θɹʌst əm ət ðə mæn. hi wɔkt ɑn ɪn ə deɪz, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə mæn boʊɪŋ ɑn ðə deɪz tə ðə klæpɪŋ ə hɪz lɪsənɝz, kɹeɪɾəlɪŋ ɪz hɑɹp ɪn wʌn ɑɹm ən wɪð ði ʌðɝ spɹɛɾɪŋ ɪz pætʃ-kʌvɝd kloʊk əz ɪf tə tʃɹæp ɔl ðə saʊn ðeɪ meɪd. hi wɑz ə tɔl mæn, læŋki ən nɑt jʌŋ, wɪð lɔŋ mʌstæʃɪz əz waɪɾ əz ðə hɛɹ ɑn ɪz hɛd. ən wən i stʃɹeɪɾənd ən sɔ ɹænd, ði aɪz ðət waɪɾənd wɝ ʃɑɹp ən blu.

Rand dug out some coins and thrust them at the man. He walked on in a daze, staring at the man bowing on the dais to the clapping of his listeners, cradling his harp in one arm and with the other spreading his patch-covered cloak as if to trap all the sound they made. He was a tall man, lanky and not young, with long mustaches as white as the hair on his head. And when he straightened and saw Rand, the eyes that widened were sharp and blue.

"tɑm." ɹændz wɪspɝ wɑz lɔst ɪn ðə nɔɪz ə ðə kɹaʊd.

"Thom." Rand's whisper was lost in the noise of the crowd.

hoʊldɪŋ ɹændz aɪ, tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn nɑɾəd slaɪtli təwɔɹɾ ə smɔl dɔɹ bɪsaɪd ðə deɪz. ðən i wɑz boʊɪŋ əɡɛn, smaɪlɪŋ ən bæskɪŋ ɪn ði əplɔz.

Holding Rand's eye, Thom Merrilin nodded slightly toward a small door beside the dais. Then he was bowing again, smiling and basking in the applause.

ɹænd meɪɾ ɪz weɪ tə ðə dɔɹ ən θɹu ɪt. ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə smɔl hɔlweɪ, wɪð θɹi stɛps liɾɪŋ ʌp tə ðə deɪz. ɪn ði ʌðɝ dɝɛkʃən fɹəm ðə deɪz ɹænd kəd si ə dʒʌɡəlɝ pɹæktəsɪŋ wɪð kʌlɝd bɔlz, ən sɪks tʌmblɝz lɪmbɝɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz.

Rand made his way to the door and through it. It was only a small hallway, with three steps leading up to the dais. In the other direction from the dais Rand could see a juggler practicing with colored balls, and six tumblers limbering themselves.

tɑm əpɪɹɾ ɑn ðə stɛps, lɪmpɪŋ əz ðoʊ hɪz ɹaɪt lɛɡ dɪd nɑt bɛn əz wɛl əz ɪt hæd. hi aɪd ðə dʒʌɡəlɝ ən ðə tʌmblɝz, blu aʊɾ ɪz mʌstæʃɪz dɪsdeɪnfəli, ən tɝn tə ɹænd. "ɔl ðeɪ wɑnə hɪɹ ɪz ðə ɡɹeɪt hʌn ə ðə hɔɹn. jə wəd θɪŋk, wɪð ðə nuz fɹəm hæɾən mɝk ən sɑldɑiə, wʌn ə ðɛm wəɾ æsk fəɹ ðə kæɹæəθən saɪkəl. wɛl, meɪbi nɑt ðæt, bʌɾ aɪd peɪ maɪsɛlf tə tɛl sʌmθɪŋ ɛls." hi lʊkt ɹænd ʌp ən daʊn. "ju lʊk əz ɪf jəɹ duɪŋ wɛl, bɔɪ." hi fɪŋɡɝd ɹændz kɑlɝ ən pɝst ɪz lɪps. "vɛɹi wɛl."

Thom appeared on the steps, limping as though his right leg did not bend as well as it had. He eyed the juggler and the tumblers, blew out his mustaches disdainfully, and turned to Rand. "All they want to hear is The Great Hunt of the Horn. You would think, with the news from Haddon Mirk and Saldaea, one of them would ask for The Karaethon Cycle. Well, maybe not that, but I'd pay myself to tell something else." He looked Rand up and down. "You look as if you're doing well, boy." He fingered Rand's collar and pursed his lips. "Very well."

ɹænd kəd nɑt hɛlp læfɪŋ. "aɪ lɛft waɪtbɹɪdʒ ʃʊɹ jə wɝ dɛd. mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd jə wɝ stɪl əlaɪv, bʌɾ aɪ. . . . laɪt, tɑm, ɪts ɡʊd tə si jə əɡɛn! aɪ ʃʊɾə ɡɔn bæk tə hɛlp ju."

Rand could not help laughing. "I left Whitebridge sure you were dead. Moiraine said you were still alive, but I. . . . Light, Thom, it's good to see you again! I should have gone back to help you."

"bɪɡɝ ful ɪf jə hæd, bɔɪ. ðət feɪd" - hi lʊkt ɝaʊnd; ðəɹ wɑz noʊ wʌn kloʊs ɪnʌf tə hɪɹ, bʌɾ i loʊɝɾ ɪz vɔɪs ɛniweɪ - "hæd noʊ ɪntʃɹəst ɪn mi. ɪt lɛf mi ə lɪɾəl pɹɛzən ʌv ə stɪf lɛɡ ən ɹæn ɔf æftɝ jə ən mæt. ɔl jə cʊɾə dʌn wɑz daɪ." hi pɔzd, lʊkɪŋ θɔtfəl. "mɔɪɹeɪn sɛɾ aɪ wɑz stɪl əlaɪv, dɪd ʃi? ɪz ʃi wɪð ju, ðɛn?"

"Bigger fool if you had, boy. That Fade" - he looked around; there was no one close enough to hear, but he lowered his voice anyway - "had no interest in me. It left me a little present of a stiff leg and ran off after you and Mat. All you could have done was die." He paused, looking thoughtful. "Moiraine said I was still alive, did she? Is she with you, then?"

ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. tə hɪz sɝpɹaɪz, tɑm sim dɪsəpɔɪntɪd.

Rand shook his head. To his surprise, Thom seemed disappointed.

"tu bæd, ɪn ə weɪ. ʃiz ə faɪn wʊmən, ivən ɪf ʃi ɪz. . . ." hi lɛft ɪɾ ənsɛd. "soʊ ɪt wɑz mæt əɹ pɛɹɪn ʃi wɑz æftɝ. aɪ woʊn æsk wɪtʃ. ðeɪ wɝ ɡʊd bɔɪz, ən aɪ doʊnt wɑnə noʊ." ɹænd ʃɪftəɾ ənizəli, ən ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt wən tɑm fɪkst ɪm wɪð ə boʊni fɪŋɡɝ. "wʌɾ aɪ də wɑnə noʊ ɪz, dʒju stɪl əv maɪ hɑɹp ən flut? aɪ wɑn əm bæk, bɔɪ. wʌɾ aɪ hæv naʊ ɑɹ nɑt fɪt fəɹ ə pɪɡ tə pleɪ."

"Too bad, in a way. She's a fine woman, even if she is. . . ." He left it unsaid. "So it was Mat or Perrin she was after. I won't ask which. They were good boys, and I don't want to know." Rand shifted uneasily, and gave a start when Thom fixed him with a bony finger. "What I do want to know is, do you still have my harp and flute? I want them back, boy. What I have now are not fit for a pig to play."

"aɪ hæv ðɛm, tɑm. əl bɹɪŋ əm tə ju, aɪ pɹɑməs. aɪ kæn bɪliv jə ɑɹ əlaɪv. ən aɪ kæn bɪliv jə ɑɹən ɪn ɪljən. ðə ɡɹeɪt hʌn sɛɾɪŋ aʊt. ðə pɹaɪz fəɹ ðə bɛs tɛlɪŋ ə ðə ɡɹeɪt hʌn ə ðə hɔɹn. jə wɝ daɪɪŋ tə ɡoʊ."

"I have them, Thom. I'll bring them to you, I promise. I can't believe you are alive. And I can't believe you aren't in Illian. The Great Hunt setting out. The prize for the best telling of The Great Hunt of the Horn. You were dying to go."

tɑm snɔɹɾɪd. "æftɝ waɪtbɹɪdʒ? laɪkli aɪd daɪ ɪf aɪ dɪd ɡoʊ. ivən ɪf aɪ cʊɾə ɹitʃt ðə boʊt bɪfɔɹ ɪt seɪld, doʊmən ən ɪz hoʊl kɹu wəd bi spɹɛɾɪŋ ðə teɪl ɔl oʊvɝ ɪljən əbaʊt haʊ aɪ wɑz biɪŋ tʃeɪs baɪ tʃɹɑləks. ɪf ðeɪ sɔ ðə feɪd, əɹ hɝɾ ʌv ɪt, bɪfɔɹ doʊmən kʌɾ ɪz laɪnz. . . . moʊst ɪliɑnɝz θɪŋk tʃɹɑləks ən feɪdz ɑɹ feɪbəlz, bʌɾ ɪnʌf ʌðɝz maɪt wɑnə noʊ waɪ ə mæn wɑz pɝsud baɪ ðɛm tə meɪk ɪljən sʌmwʌt mɔɹ ðən ənkʌmftəɹbəl."

Thom snorted. "After Whitebridge? Likely I'd die if I did go. Even if I could have reached the boat before it sailed, Domon and his whole crew would be spreading the tale all over Illian about how I was being chased by Trollocs. If they saw the Fade, or heard of it, before Domon cut his lines. . . . Most Illianers think Trollocs and Fades are fables, but enough others might want to know why a man was pursued by them to make Illian somewhat more than uncomfortable."

"tɑm, aɪ hæv soʊ mʌtʃ tə tɛl ju."

"Thom, I have so much to tell you."

ðə ɡlimən kʌɾ ɪm ɔf. "leɪɾɝ, bɔɪ." hi wɑz ɪkstʃeɪnʒɪŋ ɡlɛɹz daʊn ðə lɛŋθ ə ðə hɔl wɪð ðə nɛɹoʊ-feɪs mæn fɹəm ðə dɔɹ. "ɪf aɪ doʊnt ɡoʊ bæk ən tɛl ənʌðɝ, hɪl noʊ daʊt sɛn ðə dʒʌɡəlɝ aʊt, ən ðət lɑt wɪl tɛɹ ðə hɔl daʊn ɝaʊn əɹ hɛdz. jə kʌm tə ðə bʌntʃ ʌv ɡɹeɪps, dʒʌs bɪɑn ðə dʒæŋɡaɪ ɡeɪt. aɪ hæv ə ɹum ðɛɹ. ɛniwʌn kən tɛl jə wɛɹ tə faɪn ɪt. əl bi ðəɹ ɪn ənʌðɝ aʊɝ əɹ soʊ. wʌn mɔɹ teɪl wɪl əv tə sæɾəsfaɪ ðɛm." hi stɑɹɾəd bæk ʌp ðə stɛps, flɪŋɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, "æn bɹɪŋ maɪ hɑɹp ən maɪ flut!"

The gleeman cut him off. "Later, boy." He was exchanging glares down the length of the hall with the narrow-faced man from the door. "If I don't go back and tell another, he will no doubt send the juggler out, and that lot will tear the hall down around our heads. You come to The Bunch of Grapes, just beyond the Jangai Gate. I have a room there. Anyone can tell you where to find it. I'll be there in another hour or so. One more tale will have to satisfy them." He started back up the steps, flinging over his shoulder, "And bring my harp and my flute!"


tʃæptɝ twɛntisɪks


CHAPTER 26

dɪskɔɹd


Discord

ɹænd dɑɹɾɪd θɹu ðə kɑmən ɹum ə ðə dɪfɛndɝ ə ðə dʒɹæɡoʊnwɔl ən hɝiɾ əpstɛɹz, ɡɹɪnɪŋ ət ðə stɑɹɾəld lʊk ði ɪnkipɝ hæd ɡɪvən hɪm. ɹænd wɑntəd tə ɡɹɪn əɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ. tɑmz əlaɪv!

Rand darted through the common room of The Defender of the Dragonwall and hurried upstairs, grinning at the startled look the innkeeper had given him. Rand wanted to grin at everything. Thom's alive!

hi flʌŋ oʊpən ðə dɔɹ tə hɪz ɹum ən wɛn stʃɹeɪt tə ðə wɔɹdʒɹoʊb.

He flung open the door to his room and went straight to the wardrobe.

lɔɪəl ən hʊɹɪn pʊt ðɛɹ hɛdz ɪn fɹəm ði ʌðɝ ɹum, boʊθ ɪn ðɛɹ ʃɝtslivz ən wɪð paɪps ɪn ðɛɹ tiθ tʃɹeɪlɪŋ θɪn stʃɹimz ə smoʊk.

Loial and Hurin put their heads in from the other room, both in their shirtsleeves and with pipes in their teeth trailing thin streams of smoke.

"hæz sʌmθɪŋ hæpənd, lɔɹd ɹænd?" hʊɹɪn æskt æŋkʃəsli.

"Has something happened, Lord Rand?" Hurin asked anxiously.

ɹænd slʌŋ ðə bʌndəl meɪd fɹəm tɑmz kloʊk ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. "ðə bɛs θɪŋ ðət kʊd, nɛks tə ɪŋtʃɹ kʌmɪŋ. tɑm mɛɹɪlɪnz əlaɪv. ən hiz hɪɹ, ɪn kɛɹhin."

Rand slung the bundle made from Thom's cloak on his shoulder. "The best thing that could, next to Ingtar coming. Thom Merrilin's alive. And he's here, in Cairhien."

"ðə ɡlimən jə toʊl mi əbaʊt?" lɔɪəl sɛd. "ðæɾ ɪz wʌndɝfəl, ɹænd. aɪ wəd laɪk tə mit hɪm."

"The gleeman you told me about?" Loial said. "That is wonderful, Rand. I would like to meet him."

"ðɛn kʌm wɪð mi, ɪf hʊɹɪnz wɪlɪŋ tə kip wɑtʃ əwaɪl."

"Then come with me, if Hurin's willing to keep watch awhile."

"ɪt wəd bi ə plɛʒɝ, lɔɹd ɹænd." hʊɹɪn tʊk ðə paɪp aʊɾ ə hɪz maʊθ. "ðæt lɑɾ ɪn ðə kɑmən ɹum kɛp tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʌmp mi - wɪθaʊt lɛɾɪŋ ɑn wʌt ðeɪ wɝ duɪŋ, ʌv kɔɹs - əbaʊɾ u jə ɑɹ, maɪ lɔɹd, ən waɪ wɝ ɪn kɛɹhin. aɪ toʊld əm wi wɝ weɪɾɪŋ hɪɹ tə mit fɹɛnz, bʌt biɪŋ kɛɹhinɪn, ðeɪ fɪɡjɝɾ aɪ wɑz haɪɾɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ dipɝ."

"It would be a pleasure, Lord Rand." Hurin took the pipe out of his mouth. "That lot in the common room kept trying to pump me - without letting on what they were doing, of course - about who you are, my Lord, and why we're in Cairhien. I told them we were waiting here to meet friends, but being Cairhienin, they figured I was hiding something deeper."

"lɛɾ əm θɪŋk wʌt ðeɪ wɑnt. kʌm ɑn, lɔɪəl."

"Let them think what they want. Come on, Loial."

"aɪ θɪŋk nɑt." ði oʊɡiɝ saɪd. "aɪ ɹɪli wəd ɹæðɝ steɪ hɪɹ." hi ɹeɪzd ə bʊk wɪð ə θɪk fɪŋɡɝ mɑɹkɪŋ ɪz pleɪs. "aɪ kən mit tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn səm ʌðɝ taɪm."

"I think not." The Ogier sighed. "I really would rather stay here." He raised a book with a thick finger marking his place. "I can meet Thom Merrilin some other time."

"lɔɪəl, jə kæn steɪ kupt ʌp ɪn hɪɹ fɝɛvɝ. wi də nɑɾ ivən noʊ haʊ lɔŋ wɪl bi ɪn kɛɹhin. ɛniweɪ, wi dɪdn si ɛni oʊɡiɝ. ən ɪf wi du, ðeɪ wəd nɑt bi hʌntɪŋ fəɹ ju, wəd ðeɪ?"

"Loial, you can't stay cooped up in here forever. We do not even know how long we'll be in Cairhien. Anyway, we didn't see any Ogier. And if we do, they would not be hunting for you, would they?"

"nɑt hʌntɪŋ, pɹɪsaɪsli, bʌt. . . . ɹænd, aɪ meɪ hæv bɪn tu heɪsti ɪn livɪŋ stɛɾɪŋ ʃæŋktaɪ ðə weɪ aɪ dɪd. wən aɪ də ɡoʊ hoʊm, aɪ meɪ bi ɪn ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə tʃɹʌbəl." hɪz ɪɹz wɪltɪd. "ivən ɪf aɪ weɪɾ əntɪl aɪm əz oʊld əz ɛldɝ heɪmən. pɝhæps aɪ kəd faɪn ən əbændən stɛɾɪŋ tə steɪ ɪn əntɪl ðɛn."

"Not hunting, precisely, but. . . . Rand, I may have been too hasty in leaving Stedding Shangtai the way I did. When I do go home, I may be in a great deal of trouble." His ears wilted. "Even if I wait until I'm as old as Elder Haman. Perhaps I could find an abandoned stedding to stay in until then."

"ɪf ɛldɝ heɪmən woʊn lɛt jə kʌm bæk, jə kən lɪv ɪn ɛmənz fild. ɪts ə pɹɪɾi pleɪs." ə bjuɾəfəl pleɪs.

"If Elder Haman won't let you come back, you can live in Emond's Field. It's a pretty place." A beautiful place.

"aɪ æm ʃʊɹ ɪɾ ɪz, ɹænd, bʌt ðət wəd nɛvɝ wɝk. jə si - "

"I am sure it is, Rand, but that would never work. You see - "

"wi wɪl tɔk əbaʊɾ ɪt wən ɪt kʌmz tə ðæt, lɔɪəl. naʊ jə ɑɹ kʌmɪŋ tə si tɑm."

"We will talk about it when it comes to that, Loial. Now you are coming to see Thom."

ði oʊɡiɝ stʊd hæf əɡɛn əz tɔl əz ɹænd, bʌt ɹænd pʊʃt ɪm ɪndə hɪz lɔŋ tunɪk ən kloʊk ən daʊn ðə stɛɹz. wən ðeɪ keɪm paʊndɪŋ θɹu ðə kɑmən ɹum, ɹænd wɪŋkt ət ði ɪnkipɝ, ðən læft əɾ ɪz stɑɹɾəld lʊk. lɛɾ ɪm θɪŋk aɪm ɔf tə pleɪ hɪz blʌɾi ɡɹeɪt ɡeɪm. lɛɾ ɪm θɪŋk wʌɾ i wɑns. tɑmz əlaɪv.

The Ogier stood half again as tall as Rand, but Rand pushed him into his long tunic and cloak and down the stairs. When they came pounding through the common room, Rand winked at the innkeeper, then laughed at his startled look. Let him think I'm off to play his bloody Great Game. Let him think what he wants. Thom's alive.

wʌns θɹu ðə dʒæŋɡaɪ ɡeɪt, ɪn ði ist wɔl ə ðə sɪɾi, ɛvɹiwʌn sim tə noʊ ðə bʌntʃ ʌv ɡɹeɪps. ɹænd ən lɔɪəl kwɪkli faʊn ðɛmsɛlvz ðɛɹ, ɑn ə stʃɹit ðət wɑz kwaɪət fəɹ ðə fɔɹɡeɪt, wɪð ðə sʌn hæfweɪ daʊn ði æftɝnun skaɪ.

Once through the Jangai Gate, in the east wall of the city, everyone seemed to know The Bunch of Grapes. Rand and Loial quickly found themselves there, on a street that was quiet for the Foregate, with the sun halfway down the afternoon sky.

ɪt wɑz ən oʊl θɹi-stɔɹi stʃɹʌktʃɝ, wʊɾən ən ɹɪkəɾi, bʌt ðə kɑmən ɹum wɑz klin ən fʊl ə pipəl. səm mɛn wɝ pleɪɪŋ ət daɪs ɪn wʌn kɔɹnɝ, ən səm wɪmən ət dɑɹts ɪn ənʌðɝ. hæf hæd ðə lʊk ə kɛɹhinɪn, slaɪɾ ən peɪl, bʌt ɹænd hɝɾ ændɔɝən æksɛns əz wɛl əz ʌðɝz i dɪd nɑt noʊ. ɔl wɔɹ ðə kloʊðz ə ðə fɔɹɡeɪt, ðoʊ, ə blɛn ə ðə staɪlz ə hæf ə dʌzən kʌntʃɹiz. ə fju lʊkt ɝaʊnd wən i ən lɔɪəl keɪm ɪn, bʌt ðeɪ ɔl tɝn bæk tə wʌt ðeɪ hæd bɪn duɪŋ.

It was an old three-story structure, wooden and rickety, but the common room was clean and full of people. Some men were playing at dice in one corner, and some women at darts in another. Half had the look of Cairhienin, slight and pale, but Rand heard Andoran accents as well as others he did not know. All wore the clothes of the Foregate, though, a blend of the styles of half a dozen countries. A few looked around when he and Loial came in, but they all turned back to what they had been doing.

ði ɪnkipɝ wɑz ə wʊmən wɪð hɛɹ əz waɪɾ əz tɑmz, ən ʃɑɹp aɪz ðət stʌɾid lɔɪəl əz wɛl əz ɹænd. ʃi wɑz nɑt kɛɹhinɪn, baɪ hɝ dɑɹk skɪn ən əɹ spitʃ. "tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn? aɪ, hiz ə ɹum. tɑp ə ðə stɛɹz, fɝs dɔɹ ɑn ðə ɹaɪt. laɪkli dinə wɪl lɛt jə weɪt fəɹ ɪm ðɛɹ" - ʃi aɪd ɹændz ɹɛd koʊt, wɪð ɪts hɛɹənz ɑn ðə haɪ kɑlɝ ən ɡoʊldən bɹæmbəlz ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ʌp ðə slivz, ən ɪz sɔɹd - "maɪ lɔɹd."

The innkeeper was a woman with hair as white as Thom's, and sharp eyes that studied Loial as well as Rand. She was not Cairhienin, by her dark skin and her speech. "Thom Merrilin? Aye, he has a room. Top of the stairs, first door on the right. Likely Dena will let you wait for him there" - she eyed Rand's red coat, with its herons on the high collar and golden brambles embroidered up the sleeves, and his sword - "my Lord."

ðə stɛɹz kɹikt ʌndɝ ɹændz buts, lɛɾ əloʊn lɔɪəlz. ɹænd wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ɪf ðə bɪldɪŋ wəd stæn ʌp mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ. hi faʊn ðə dɔɹ ən nɑkt, wʌndɝɪŋ u dinə wɑz.

The stairs creaked under Rand's boots, let alone Loial's. Rand was not sure if the building would stand up much longer. He found the door and knocked, wondering who Dena was.

"kʌm ɪn," ə wʊmənz vɔɪs kɔld. "aɪ kænɑɾ oʊpən ɪt fəɹ ju."

"Come in," a woman's voice called. "I cannot open it for you."

ɹænd oʊpən ðə dɔɹ hɛzɪɾəntli ən pʊɾ ɪz hɛɾ ɪn. ə bɪɡ, ɹʌmpəl bɛd wɑz ʃʌvd əɡɛnst wʌn wɔl, ən ðə ɹɛst ə ðə ɹum wɑz ɔl bʌt teɪkən ʌp baɪ ə pɛɹ ʌv wɔɹdʒɹoʊbz, sɛvɹəl bɹæs-baʊn tʃɹʌŋks ən tʃɛsts, ə teɪbəl ən tu wʊɾən tʃɛɹz. ðə slɛndɝ wʊmən sɪɾɪŋ kɹɔs-lɛɡəɾ ɑn ðə bɛd wɪð əɹ skɝts tʌkt ʌndɝ əɹ wɑz kipɪŋ sɪks kʌlɝd bɔlz spɪnɪŋ ɪn ə wil bɪtwin əɹ hænz.

Rand opened the door hesitantly and put his head in. A big, rumpled bed was shoved against one wall, and the rest of the room was all but taken up by a pair of wardrobes, several brass-bound trunks and chests, a table and two wooden chairs. The slender woman sitting cross-legged on the bed with her skirts tucked under her was keeping six colored balls spinning in a wheel between her hands.

"wʌtɛvɝ ɪɾ ɪz," ʃi sɛd, lʊkɪŋ əɾ əɹ dʒʌɡəlɪŋ, "liv ɪɾ ɑn ðə teɪbəl. tɑm wɪl peɪ jə wən i kʌmz bæk."

"Whatever it is," she said, looking at her juggling, "leave it on the table. Thom will pay you when he comes back."

"ɑɹ jə dinə?" ɹænd æskt.

"Are you Dena?" Rand asked.

ʃi snætʃt ðə bɔlz aʊɾ ə ði ɛɹ ən tɝn tə ɹəɡɑɹd hɪm. ʃi wɑz oʊnli ə hændfʊl ə jɪɹz oʊldɝ ðən hi, pɹɪɾi, wɪð fɛɹ kɛɹhinɪn skɪn ən dɑɹk hɛɹ hæŋɪŋ lus tə hɝ ʃoʊldɝz. "aɪ də nɑt noʊ ju. ðɪs ɪz maɪ ɹum, maɪn ən tɑm mɛɹɪlɪnz."

She snatched the balls out of the air and turned to regard him. She was only a handful of years older than he, pretty, with fair Cairhienin skin and dark hair hanging loose to her shoulders. "I do not know you. This is my room, mine and Thom Merrilin's."

"ði ɪnkipɝ sɛd jə maɪt lɛɾ əs weɪt hɪɹ fəɹ tɑm," ɹænd sɛd. "ɪf jəɹ dinə?"

"The innkeeper said you might let us wait here for Thom," Rand said. "If you're Dena?"

"ʌs?" ɹænd muvd ɪndə ðə ɹum soʊ lɔɪəl kəd dʌk ɪnsaɪd, ən ðə jʌŋ wʊmənz aɪbɹaʊz lɪftəd. "soʊ ði oʊɡiɝ əv kʌm bæk. aɪm dinə. wʌt dʒju wɑnt?" ʃi lʊkt ət ɹændz koʊt soʊ dɪlɪbɝətli ðət ðə feɪljɝ tə æd "maɪ lɔɹd" hæd tə bi pɝpəsfəl, ðoʊ hɝ bɹaʊz wɛn ʌp əɡɛn ət ðə hɛɹənz ɑn ɪz skæbɝɾ ən sɔɹd hɪlt.

"Us?" Rand moved into the room so Loial could duck inside, and the young woman's eyebrows lifted. "So the Ogier have come back. I am Dena. What do you want?" She looked at Rand's coat so deliberately that the failure to add "my Lord" had to be purposeful, though her brows went up again at the herons on his scabbard and sword hilt.

ɹænd hɛftəd ðə bʌndəl i kæɹid. "aɪv bɹɔt tɑm bæk ɪz hɑɹp ən ɪz flut. ən aɪ wɑnə vɪzət wɪð hɪm," hi æɾəd kwɪkli; ʃi simd ɑn ðə pɔɪn ə tɛlɪŋ ɪm tə liv ðɛm. "aɪ hævən sin ɪm ɪn ə lɔŋ taɪm."

Rand hefted the bundle he carried. "I've brought Thom back his harp and his flute. And I want to visit with him," he added quickly; she seemed on the point of telling him to leave them. "I haven't seen him in a long time."

ʃi aɪd ðə bʌndəl. "tɑm ɔlweɪz moʊnz əbaʊt luzɪŋ ðə bɛs fluɾ ən ðə bɛs hɑɹp i ɛvɝ hæd. jə wəd θɪŋk i wɑz ə kɔɹt-bɑɹd, ðə weɪ hi kæɹiz ɑn. vɛɹi wɛl. jə kən weɪt, bʌɾ aɪ mʌs pɹæktəs. tɑm sɛz hɪl lemi pɝfɔɹm ɪn ðə hɔlz nɛkst wik." ʃi ɹoʊz ɡɹeɪsfəli ən tʊk wʌn ə ðə tu tʃɛɹz, moʊʃənɪŋ lɔɪəl tə sɪɾ ɑn ðə bɛd. "zɛɹə wəd meɪk tɑm peɪ fəɹ sɪks tʃɛɹz ɪf jə bɹoʊk wʌn ə ðiz, fɹɛn oʊɡiɝ."

She eyed the bundle. "Thom always moans about losing the best flute and the best harp he ever had. You would think he was a court-bard, the way he carries on. Very well. You can wait, but I must practice. Thom says he will let me perform in the halls next week." She rose gracefully and took one of the two chairs, motioning Loial to sit on the bed. "Zera would make Thom pay for six chairs if you broke one of these, friend Ogier."

ɹænd ɡeɪv ðɛɹ neɪmz əz i sæɾ ɪn ði ʌðɝ tʃɛɹ - ɪt kɹikt əlɑɹmɪŋli ʌndɝ ivən ɪz weɪt - ən æsk daʊtfəli, "ɑɹ jə tɑmz əpɹɛntəs?"

Rand gave their names as he sat in the other chair - it creaked alarmingly under even his weight - and asked doubtfully, "Are you Thom's apprentice?"

dinə ɡeɪv ə smɔl smaɪl. "ju maɪt seɪ ðæt." ʃi hæd ɹɪzumd əɹ dʒʌɡəlɪŋ, ən əɹ aɪz wɝ ɑn ðə wɝlɪŋ bɔlz.

Dena gave a small smile. "You might say that." She had resumed her juggling, and her eyes were on the whirling balls.

"aɪ hæv nɛvɝ hɝɾ ʌv ə wʊmən ɡlimən," lɔɪəl sɛd.

"I have never heard of a woman gleeman," Loial said.

"aɪ wɪl bi ðə fɝst." ðə wʌn bɪɡ sɝkəl bɪkeɪm tu smɔlɝ, oʊvɝlæpɪŋ sɝkəlz. "aɪ wɪl si ðə hoʊl wɝl bɪfɔɹ aɪm dʌn. tɑm sɛz wʌns wɪv ɪnʌf mʌni, wɪl ɡoʊ daʊn tə tɛɹ." ʃi swɪtʃt tə dʒʌɡəlɪŋ θɹi bɔlz ɪn itʃ hænd. "æn ðən meɪbi aʊt tə ðə si foʊks aɪlənz. ði æθɑn maɪɹ peɪ ɡlimən wɛl."

"I will be the first." The one big circle became two smaller, overlapping circles. "I will see the whole world before I am done. Thom says once we have enough money, we will go down to Tear." She switched to juggling three balls in each hand. "And then maybe out to the Sea Folk's islands. The Atha'an Miere pay gleemen well."

ɹænd aɪd ðə ɹum, wɪð ɔl ðə tʃɛsts ən tʃɹʌŋks. ɪt dɪd nɑt lʊk laɪk ðə ɹum ə sʌmwʌn ɪntɛndɪŋ tə muv ɑn sun. ðəɹ wɑz ivən ə flaʊɝ ɡɹoʊɪŋ ɪn ə pɑɾ ɑn ðə wɪndaʊsəl. hɪz ɡeɪz fɛl ɑn ðə sɪŋɡəl bɪɡ bɛd, wɛɹ lɔɪəl wɑz sɪɾɪŋ. ðɪs ɪz maɪ ɹum, maɪn ən tɑm mɛɹɪlɪnz. dinə ɡeɪv ɪm ə tʃælənʒɪŋ lʊk θɹu ðə lɑɹdʒ wil ʃi hæd ɹɪzumd. ɹændz feɪs ɹɛɾənd.

Rand eyed the room, with all the chests and trunks. It did not look like the room of someone intending to move on soon. There was even a flower growing in a pot on the windowsill. His gaze fell on the single big bed, where Loial was sitting. This is my room, mine and Thom Merrilin's. Dena gave him a challenging look through the large wheel she had resumed. Rand's face reddened.

hi klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊt. "meɪbi wi ɔt tə weɪt daʊnstɛɹz," hi bɪɡæn wən ðə dɔɹ oʊpən ən tɑm keɪm ɪn wɪð ɪz kloʊk flæpɪŋ ɝaʊn ɪz æŋkəlz, pætʃəz flʌɾɝɪŋ. keɪs fluɾ ən hɑɹp hʌŋ ɑn ɪz bæk; ðə keɪsəz wɝ ɹɛɾɪʃ wʊd, pɑlɪʃt baɪ hænlɪŋ.

He cleared his throat. "Maybe we ought to wait downstairs," he began when the door opened and Thom came in with his cloak flapping around his ankles, patches fluttering. Cased flute and harp hung on his back; the cases were reddish wood, polished by handling.

dinə meɪd ðə bɔlz dɪsəpɪɹ ɪnsaɪɾ əɹ dʒɹɛs ən ɹæn tə θɹoʊ hɝ ɑɹmz ɝaʊn tɑmz nɛk, stændɪŋ ɑtɪptoʊ tə də ɪt. "aɪ mɪs ju," ʃi sɛd, ən kɪs hɪm.

Dena made the balls disappear inside her dress and ran to throw her arms around Thom's neck, standing atiptoe to do it. "I missed you," she said, and kissed him.

ðə kɪs wɛn ɑn fəɹ səm taɪm, soʊ lɔŋ ðət ɹænd wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə wʌndɝ ɪf i ən lɔɪəl ʃəd liv, bʌt dinə lɛɾ əɹ hilz dʒɹɑp tə ðə flɔɹ wɪð ə saɪ.

The kiss went on for some time, so long that Rand was beginning to wonder if he and Loial should leave, but Dena let her heels drop to the floor with a sigh.

"du jə noʊ wʌt ðət læk-wɪt sihænz dʌn naʊ, ɡɝl?" tɑm sɛd, lʊkɪŋ daʊn ət hɝ. "hiz teɪkən ɑn ə pæk ə laʊts u kɔl ðɛmsɛlvz 'pleɪɝz.' ðeɪ wɔk ɝaʊn pɹitɛndɪŋ tə bi ɹəɡoʊʃ iɡəl-aɪ, ən blz, ən ɡeɪɾəl keɪn, ænd. . . . ɑɡ! ðeɪ hæŋ ə skɹæp ə peɪntəd kænvəs bɪhaɪn ðɛm, səpoʊz tə meɪk ði ɑɾiəns bɪliv ðiz fulz ɑɹ ɪn mətukɪn hɔl, əɹ ðə haɪ pæsəz ə ðə maʊntənz ə dum. aɪ meɪk ðə lɪsənɝ si ɛvɹi bænɝ, smɛl ɛvɹi bæɾəl, fil ɛvɹi ɪmoʊʃən. aɪ meɪk əm bɪliv ðeɪ ɑɹ ɡeɪɾəl keɪn. sihæn wɪl əv ɪz hɔl tɔɹn daʊn ɝaʊn ɪz ɪɹz ɪf i pʊts ðɪs lɑɾ ɑn tə fɑloʊ mi."

"Do you know what that lack-wit Seaghan's done now, girl?" Thom said, looking down at her. "He's taken on a pack of louts who call themselves 'players.' They walk around pretending to be Rogosh Eagle-eye, and Blaes, and Gaidal Cain, and. . . . Aaagh!
