They hang a scrap of painted canvas behind them, supposed to make the audience believe these fools are in Matuchin Hall, or the high passes of the Mountains of Dhoom. I make the listener see every banner, smell every battle, feel every emotion. I make them believe they are Gaidal Cain. Seaghan will have his hall torn down around his ears if he puts this lot on to follow me."

"tɑm, wɪv vɪzəɾɝz. lɔɪəl, sʌn ʌv ɑɹən sʌn ə hɑlən. oʊ, ən ə bɔɪ hu kɔlz hɪmsɛlf ɹænd ælθɹ."

"Thom, we have visitors. Loial, son of Arent son of Halan. Oh, and a boy who calls himself Rand al'Thor."

tɑm lʊkt oʊvɝ əɹ hɛɾ ət ɹænd, fɹaʊnɪŋ. "liv əs fəɹ ə waɪl, dinə. hɪɹ." hi pɹɛst səm sɪlvɝ kɔɪnz ɪndə hɝ hænd. "jɔɹ naɪvz ɑɹ ɹɛɾi. waɪ doʊn jə ɡoʊ peɪ aɪvn fəɹ ðɛm?" hi bɹʌʃt əɹ smuð tʃik wɪð ə nɑɹl nʌkəl. "ɡoʊ ɑn. əl meɪk ɪɾ ʌp tə ju."

Thom looked over her head at Rand, frowning. "Leave us for a while, Dena. Here." He pressed some silver coins into her hand. "Your knives are ready. Why don't you go pay Ivon for them?" He brushed her smooth cheek with a gnarled knuckle. "Go on. I'll make it up to you."

ʃi ɡeɪv ɪm ə dɑɹk lʊk, bʌt ʃi tɔst əɹ kloʊk ɝaʊn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz, mʌɾɝɪŋ, "aɪvn bɛɾɝ əv ðə bæləns ɹaɪt."

She gave him a dark look, but she tossed her cloak around her shoulders, muttering, "Ivon better have the balance right."

"ʃil bi ə bɑɹd wʌn deɪ," tɑm sɛd wɪð ə noʊɾ ə pɹaɪɾ æftɝ ʃi wɑz ɡɔn. "ʃi lɪsənz tə ə teɪl wʌns - wʌns oʊnli, maɪnd! - ən ʃiz ɪt ɹaɪt, nɑt dʒʌs ðə wɝdz, bʌɾ ɛvɹi nuɑns, ɛvɹi ɹɪðəm. ʃiz ə faɪn hæn ɑn ðə hɑɹp, ən ʃi pleɪd ðə flut bɛɾɝ ðə fɝs taɪm ʃi pɪkt ɪɾ ʌp ðən jə ɛvɝ dɪd." hi sɛt ðə wʊɾən ɪnstʃɹəmən keɪsəz ətɑp wʌn ə ðə lɑɹdʒɝ tʃɹʌŋks, ðən dʒɹɑpt ɪndə ðə tʃɛɹ ʃi hæɾ əbændənd. "wɛn aɪ pæs θɹu keɪɛmlɪn ɑn ðə weɪ hɪɹ, bɑzəl ɡɪl toʊl mi jud lɛft ɪn kʌmpəni wɪð ən oʊɡiɝ. əmʌŋ ʌðɝz." hi baʊd təwɔɹd lɔɪəl, ivən mænɪdʒɪŋ ə flɝɪʃ ə hɪz kloʊk dɪspaɪt ðə fæk ðəɾ i wɑz sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ɪt. "aɪ æm pliz tə mit ju, lɔɪəl, sʌn ʌv ɑɹən sʌn ə hɑlən."

"She'll be a bard one day," Thom said with a note of pride after she was gone. "She listens to a tale once - once only, mind! - and she has it right, not just the words, but every nuance, every rhythm. She has a fine hand on the harp, and she played the flute better the first time she picked it up than you ever did." He set the wooden instrument cases atop one of the larger trunks, then dropped into the chair she had abandoned. "When I passed through Caemlyn on the way here, Basel Gill told me you'd left in company with an Ogier. Among others." He bowed toward Loial, even managing a flourish of his cloak despite the fact that he was sitting on it. "I am pleased to meet you, Loial, son of Arent son of Halan."

"æn aɪ tə mit ju, tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn." lɔɪəl stʊd tə meɪk ɪz baʊ ɪn ɹɪtɝn; wən i stʃɹeɪɾənd, hɪz hɛɾ ɔlmoʊs bɹʌʃt ðə silɪŋ, ən i kwɪkli sæt daʊn əɡɛn. "ðə jʌŋ wʊmən sɛd ʃi wɑns tə bi ə ɡlimən."

"And I to meet you, Thom Merrilin." Loial stood to make his bow in return; when he straightened, his head almost brushed the ceiling, and he quickly sat down again. "The young woman said she wants to be a gleeman."

tɑmz hɛd ʃeɪk wɑz dɪspɛɹɪdʒɪŋ. "ðæts noʊ laɪf fəɹ ə wʊmən. nɑt mʌtʃ ʌv ə laɪf fəɹ ə mæn, fəɹ ðæt. wɑndɝɪŋ fɹəm taʊn tə taʊn, vɪlədʒ tə vɪlədʒ, wʌndɝɪŋ haʊ ðəl tʃɹaɪ tə tʃit jə ðɪs taɪm, hæf ðə taɪm wʌndɝɪŋ wɛɹ jəɹ nɛks mil ɪz kʌmɪŋ fɹʌm. noʊ, əl tɔk əɹ ɝaʊnd. ʃɪl bi kɔɹt-bɑɹd tə ə kɪŋ əɹ ə kwin bɪfɔɹ ʃiz dʌn. ɑə! jə dɪdn kʌm hɪɹ tə tɔk əbaʊt dinə. maɪ ɪnstʃɹəməns, bɔɪ. juv bɹɔt ðɛm?"

Thom's head shake was disparaging. "That's no life for a woman. Not much of a life for a man, for that. Wandering from town to town, village to village, wondering how they'll try to cheat you this time, half the time wondering where your next meal is coming from. No, I'll talk her around. She'll be court-bard to a king or a queen before she's done. Aaaah! You didn't come here to talk about Dena. My instruments, boy. You've brought them?"

ɹænd pʊʃt ðə bʌndəl əkɹɔs ðə teɪbəl. tɑm əndɪɾ ɪt hɝidli - hi blɪŋkt wən i sɔ ɪt wɑz ɪz oʊl kloʊk, ɔl kʌvɝd wɪð kʌlɝfəl pætʃəz laɪk ðə wʌn i wɔɹ - ən oʊpən ðə hɑɹd lɛðɝ flut keɪs, nɑɾɪŋ ət ðə saɪɾ ə ðə ɡoʊld-ænd-sɪlvɝ flut nɛsəld ɪnsaɪd.

Rand pushed the bundle across the table. Thom undid it hurriedly - he blinked when he saw it was his old cloak, all covered with colorful patches like the one he wore - and opened the hard leather flute case, nodding at the sight of the gold-and-silver flute nestled inside.

"aɪ ɝn maɪ bɛɾ ən milz wɪð ðəɾ æftɝ wi pɑɹɾəd," ɹænd sɛd.

"I earned my bed and meals with that after we parted," Rand said.

"aɪ noʊ," ðə ɡlimən ɹɪplaɪd dʒɹaɪli. "aɪ stɑpt ət səm ə ðə seɪm ɪnz, bʌɾ aɪ hæd tə meɪk də wɪð dʒʌɡəlɪŋ ən ə fju sɪmpəl stɔɹiz sɪns jə hæd maɪ - jə dɪdn tʌtʃ ðə hɑɹp?" hi pʊld oʊpən ði ʌðɝ dɑɹk lɛðɝ keɪs ən tʊk aʊɾ ə ɡoʊld-ænd-sɪlvɝ hɑɹp əz ɔɹneɪɾ əz ðə flut, kɹeɪɾəlɪŋ ɪɾ ɪn ɪz hænz laɪk ə beɪbi. "jɔɹ klʌmzi ʃifɝɾɝz fɪŋɡɝz wɝ nɛvɝ mɛn fəɹ ðə hɑɹp."

"I know," the gleeman replied dryly. "I stopped at some of the same inns, but I had to make do with juggling and a few simple stories since you had my - You didn't touch the harp?" He pulled open the other dark leather case and took out a gold-and-silver harp as ornate as the flute, cradling it in his hands like a baby. "Your clumsy sheepherder's fingers were never meant for the harp."

"aɪ dɪdn tʌtʃ ɪt," ɹænd əʃʊɹd hɪm.

"I didn't touch it," Rand assured him.

tɑm plʌk tu stʃɹɪŋz, wɪnsɪŋ. "æt lis jə wɝn ful ɪnʌf tə tʃɹaɪ kipɪŋ ɪt tund," hi mʌɾɝd. "kʊɾ əv ɹuən ɪt."

Thom plucked two strings, wincing. "At least you weren't fool enough to try keeping it tuned," he muttered. "Could have ruined it."

ɹænd lin əkɹɔs ðə teɪbəl təwɔɹd hɪm. "tɑm, jə wɑntəd tə ɡoʊ tə ɪljən, tə si ðə ɡɹeɪt hʌn sɛɾ aʊt, ən bi wʌn ə ðə fɝs tə meɪk nu stɔɹiz əbaʊɾ ɪt, bʌt jə kʊdnt. wʌt wəd jə seɪ ɪf aɪ toʊl jə jə kəd stɪl bi ə pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt? ə bɪɡ pɑɹt?"

Rand leaned across the table toward him. "Thom, you wanted to go to Illian, to see the Great Hunt set out, and be one of the first to make new stories about it, but you couldn't. What would you say if I told you you could still be a part of it? A big part?"

lɔɪəl stɝɾ ənizəli. "ɹænd, ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ . . . ?" ɹænd weɪvd ɪm tə saɪləns, hɪz aɪz ɑn tɑm.

Loial stirred uneasily. "Rand, are you sure . . . ?" Rand waved him to silence, his eyes on Thom.

tɑm ɡlænst ət ði oʊɡiɝ ən fɹaʊnd. "ðæt wəd dɪpɛn ɑn wʌt pɑɹt, ən haʊ. ɪf juv ɹizən tə bɪliv wʌn ə ðə hʌntɝz ɪz kʌmɪŋ ðɪs weɪ. . . . aɪ səpoʊz ðeɪ cʊɾə lɛft ɪljən ɔlɹɛɾi, bʌt hid bi wiks ɹitʃɪŋ hɪɹ ɪf i ɹoʊd stʃɹeɪɾ ɑn, ən waɪ wəd hi? ɪz ðɪs wʌn ə ðə fɛloʊz u nɛvɝ wɛn tə ɪljən? hɪl nɛvɝ meɪk ɪɾ ɪndə ðə stɔɹiz wɪθaʊt ðə blɛsɪŋ, wʌtɛvɝ i dʌz."

Thom glanced at the Ogier and frowned. "That would depend on what part, and how. If you've reason to believe one of the Hunters is coming this way. . . . I suppose they could have left Illian already, but he'd be weeks reaching here if he rode straight on, and why would he? Is this one of the fellows who never went to Illian? He'll never make it into the stories without the blessing, whatever he does."

"ɪt dʌzn mæɾɝ ɪf ðə hʌn əz lɛft ɪljən əɹ nɑt." ɹænd hɝd lɔɪəlz bɹɛθ kætʃ. "tɑm, wɪv ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ."

"It doesn't matter if the Hunt has left Illian or not." Rand heard Loial's breath catch. "Thom, we have the Horn of Valere."

fəɹ ə moʊmən ðəɹ wɑz dɛd saɪləns. tɑm bɹoʊk ɪt wɪð ə ɡɹeɪt ɡʌfɔ ʌv læftɝ. "ju tu hæv ðə hɔɹn? ə ʃɛpɝɾ ən ə bɪɹdləs oʊɡiɝ əv ðə hɔɹn ʌv. . . ." hi dʌbəld oʊvɝ, paʊndɪŋ ɪz ni. "ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ!"

For a moment there was dead silence. Thom broke it with a great guffaw of laughter. "You two have the Horn? A shepherd and a beardless Ogier have the Horn of. . . ." He doubled over, pounding his knee. "The Horn of Valere!"

"bʌt wi də hæv ɪt," lɔɪəl sɛd sɪɹiəsli.

"But we do have it," Loial said seriously.

tɑm dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ. smɔl æftɝʃɑks ə læftɝ stɪl sim tə kætʃ ɪm ʌnəwɛɹ. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt jə faʊnd, bʌɾ aɪ kən teɪk jə tə tɛn tævɝnz wɛɹ ə fɛloʊ wɪl tɛl jə ðəɾ i noʊz ə mæn u noʊz ðə mæn huz ɔlɹɛɾi faʊn ðə hɔɹn, ən hɪl tɛl jə haʊ ɪt wɑz faʊnd, tu - əz lɔŋ əz jə baɪ hɪz eɪl. aɪ kən teɪk jə tə θɹi mɛn u wɪl sɛl jə ðə hɔɹn, ən swɛɹ ðɛɹ soʊlz ʌndɝ ðə laɪɾ ɪts ðə ɹil wʌn ən tʃɹu. ðəɹ ɪz ivən ə lɔɹɾ ɪn ðə sɪɾi hæz wʌɾ i kleɪmz ɪz ðə hɔɹn lɑkt ʌp ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz mænɝ. hi sɛz ɪts ə tʃɹɛʒɝ hændəd daʊn ɪn ɪz haʊs sɪns ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ. aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɪf ðə hʌntɝz wɪl ɛvɝ faɪn ðə hɔɹn, bʌt ðəl hʌn daʊn tɛn θaʊzən laɪz əlɔŋ ðə weɪ."

Thom drew a deep breath. Small aftershocks of laughter still seemed to catch him unaware. "I don't know what you found, but I can take you to ten taverns where a fellow will tell you that he knows a man who knows the man who's already found the Horn, and he will tell you how it was found, too - as long as you buy his ale. I can take you to three men who will sell you the Horn, and swear their souls under the Light it's the real one and true. There is even a lord in the city has what he claims is the Horn locked up inside his manor. He says it's a treasure handed down in his House since the Breaking. I don't know if the Hunters will ever find the Horn, but they will hunt down ten thousand lies along the way."

"mɔɪɹeɪn sɛz ɪts ðə hɔɹn," ɹænd sɛd.

"Moiraine says it's the Horn," Rand said.

tɑmz mɝθ wɑz kʌt ʃɔɹt. "ʃi dʌz, dʌz ʃi? aɪ θɔt jə sɛd ʃi wɑz nɑt wɪð ju."

Thom's mirth was cut short. "She does, does she? I thought you said she was not with you."

"ʃi ɪzənt, tɑm. aɪ hæv nɑt sin əɹ sɪns aɪ lɛft fæl dæɹə, ɪn ʃaɪnɝ, ən fəɹ ə mʌnθ bɪfɔɹ ðət ʃi sɛd noʊ mɔɹ ðən tu wɝdz təɡɛðɝ tə mi." hi kəd nɑt kip ðə bɪɾɝnəs aʊɾ ə hɪz vɔɪs. ən wən ʃi dɪd tɔk, aɪ wɪʃt ʃid kɛpt ɑn ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ mi. əl nɛvɝ dæns tə hɝ tun əɡɛn, ðə laɪt bɝn əɹ ən ɛvɹi ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ. noʊ. nɑɾ ɛɡwin. nɑt nɪneɪiv. hi wɑz kɑnʃəs ə tɑm wɑtʃɪŋ ɪm kloʊsli. "ʃi ɪzən hɪɹ, tɑm. aɪ də nɑt noʊ wɛɹ ʃi ɪz, ən aɪ də nɑt kɛɹ."

"She isn't, Thom. I have not seen her since I left Fal Dara, in Shienar, and for a month before that she said no more than two words together to me." He could not keep the bitterness out of his voice. And when she did talk, I wished she'd kept on ignoring me. I'll never dance to her tune again, the Light burn her and every other Aes Sedai. No. Not Egwene. Not Nynaeve. He was conscious of Thom watching him closely. "She isn't here, Thom. I do not know where she is, and I do not care."

"wɛl, ət lis juv sɛns ɪnʌf tə kip ɪt sikɹət. ɪf jə hædnt, ɪt wəd bi ɔl oʊvɝ ðə fɔɹɡeɪt baɪ naʊ, ən hæf ə kɛɹhin wəd bi laɪɪŋ ɪn weɪt tə teɪk ɪɾ əweɪ. hæf ðə wɝld."

"Well, at least you have sense enough to keep it secret. If you hadn't, it would be all over the Foregate by now, and half of Cairhien would be lying in wait to take it away. Half the world."

"oʊ, wiv kɛpt ɪt sikɹət, tɑm. ən aɪ hæv tə bɹɪŋ ɪt bæk tə fæl dæɹə wɪθaʊt dɑɹkfɹɛnz əɹ ɛniwʌn ɛls teɪkɪŋ ɪɾ əweɪ. ðæts stɔɹi ɪnʌf fəɹ jə ɹaɪt ðɛɹ, ɪzən ɪt? aɪ kəd juz ə fɹɛn u noʊz ðə wɝld. juv bɪn ɛvɹiwɛɹ; jə noʊ θɪŋz aɪ kæn ivən ɪmædʒən. lɔɪəl ən hʊɹɪn noʊ mɔɹ ðən aɪ du, bʌt wɝ ɔl θɹi flaʊndɝɪŋ ɪn dip wɔɾɝ."

"Oh, we've kept it secret, Thom. And I have to bring it back to Fal Dara without Darkfriends or anyone else taking it away. That's story enough for you right there, isn't it? I could use a friend who knows the world. You've been everywhere; you know things I can't even imagine. Loial and Hurin know more than I do, but we're all three floundering in deep water."

"hʊɹɪn . . . ? noʊ, doʊn tɛl mi haʊ. aɪ də nɑt wɑnə noʊ." ðə ɡlimən pʊʃt bæk ɪz tʃɛɹ ən wɛn tə stɛɹ aʊɾ ə ðə wɪndoʊ. "ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ. ðət minz ðə læs bæɾəl ɪz kʌmɪŋ. hu wɪl noʊɾəs? dɪd jə si ðə pipəl læfɪŋ ɪn ðə stʃɹits aʊt ðɛɹ? lɛt ðə ɡɹeɪn bɑɹdʒəz stɑp ə wik, ən ðeɪ woʊn læf. ɡɔlʒɹiən wɪl θɪŋk ðeɪv ɔl bɪkʌm il. ðə noʊbəlz ɔl pleɪ ðə ɡeɪm ə haʊsəz, skimɪŋ tə ɡɛt kloʊs tə ðə kɪŋ, skimɪŋ tə ɡeɪn mɔɹ paʊɝ ðən ðə kɪŋ, skimɪŋ tə pʊl daʊn ɡɔlʒɹiən ən bi ðə nɛks kɪŋ. əɹ kwin. ðəl θɪŋk tɑɹmən ɡdən ɪz oʊnli ə plɔɪ ɪn ðə ɡeɪm." hi tɝn əweɪ fɹəm ðə wɪndoʊ. "aɪ doʊn səpoʊz jə ɑɹ tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt sɪmpli ɹaɪɾɪŋ tə ʃaɪnɝ ən hændɪŋ ðə hɔɹn tə - hu? - ðə kɪŋ? waɪ ʃaɪnɝ? ðə lɛdʒənz ɔl taɪ ðə hɔɹn tə ɪljən."

"Hurin . . . ? No, don't tell me how. I do not want to know." The gleeman pushed back his chair and went to stare out of the window. "The Horn of Valere. That means the Last Battle is coming. Who will notice? Did you see the people laughing in the streets out there? Let the grain barges stop a week, and they won't laugh. Galldrian will think they've all become Aiel. The nobles all play the Game of Houses, scheming to get close to the King, scheming to gain more power than the King, scheming to pull down Galldrian and be the next King. Or Queen. They will think Tarmon Gai'don is only a ploy in the Game." He turned away from the window. "I don't suppose you are talking about simply riding to Shienar and handing the Horn to - who? - the King? Why Shienar? The legends all tie the Horn to Illian."

ɹænd lʊkt ət lɔɪəl. ði oʊɡiɝz ɪɹz wɝ sæɡɪŋ. "ʃaɪnɝ, kəz aɪ noʊ hu tə ɡɪv ɪt tə, ðɛɹ. ən ðəɹ ɑɹ tʃɹɑləks ən dɑɹkfɹɛnz æftɝ ʌs."

Rand looked at Loial. The Ogier's ears were sagging. "Shienar, because I know who to give it to, there. And there are Trollocs and Darkfriends after us."

"waɪ dʌz ðət nɑt sɝpɹaɪz mi? noʊ. aɪ meɪ bi ən oʊl ful, bʌɾ əl bi ən oʊl ful ɪn maɪ oʊn weɪ. jə teɪk ðə ɡlɔɹi, bɔɪ."

"Why does that not surprise me? No. I may be an old fool, but I will be an old fool in my own way. You take the glory, boy."

"tɑm - "

"Thom - "

"noʊ!"

"No!"

ðəɹ wɑz ə saɪləns, bɹoʊkən oʊnli baɪ ðə kɹikɪŋ ə ðə bɛɾ əz lɔɪəl ʃɪftəd. faɪnəli, ɹænd sɛd, "lɔɪəl, wəd jə maɪn livɪŋ tɑm ən mi əloʊn fəɹ ə bɪt? pliz?"

There was a silence, broken only by the creaking of the bed as Loial shifted. Finally, Rand said, "Loial, would you mind leaving Thom and me alone for a bit? Please?"

lɔɪəl lʊk sɝpɹaɪzd - ðə tʌfs ɑn ɪz ɪɹz wɛn ɔlmoʊs tə pɔɪns - bʌɾ i nɑɾəd ən ɹoʊz. "ðæt daɪs ɡeɪm ɪn ðə kɑmən ɹum lʊkt ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ. pɝhæps ðəl lemi pleɪ." tɑm aɪd ɹænd səspɪʃəsli əz ðə dɔɹ kloʊz bɪhaɪn ði oʊɡiɝ.

Loial looked surprised - the tufts on his ears went almost to points - but he nodded and rose. "That dice game in the common room looked interesting. Perhaps they will let me play." Thom eyed Rand suspiciously as the door closed behind the Ogier.

ɹænd hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. ðəɹ wɝ θɪŋz i niɾəd tə noʊ, θɪŋz i wɑz ʃʊɹ tɑm nu - ðə ɡlimən hæd wʌns sim tə noʊ ə ɡɹeɪt dil əbaʊɾ ə sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ nʌmbɝ ə θɪŋz - bʌɾ i wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ haʊ tə æsk. "tɑm," hi sɛɾ ət læst, "ɑɹ ðəɹ ɛni bʊks ðəɾ əv ðə kæɹæəθən saɪkəl ɪn ðɛm?" iziɝ tə kɔl ɪt ðət ðən ðə pɹɑfəsiz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən.

Rand hesitated. There were things he needed to know, things he was sure Thom knew - the gleeman had once seemed to know a great deal about a surprising number of things - but he was not sure how to ask. "Thom," he said at last, "are there any books that have The Karaethon Cycle in them?" Easier to call it that than the Prophecies of the Dragon.

"ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪt laɪbɹɛɹiz," tɑm sɛd sloʊli. "ɛni nʌmbɝ ə tʃɹænzleɪʃənz, ən ivən ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, hɪɹ ən ðɛɹ." ɹænd stɑɹɾəd tə æsk ɪf ðəɹ wɑz ɛni weɪ fəɹ ɪm tə faɪnd wʌn, bʌt ðə ɡlimən wɛn ɑn. "ði oʊl tʌŋ əz mjuzɪk ɪn ɪt, bʌt tu mɛni ivən ə ðə noʊbəlz ɑɹ ɪmpeɪʃənt wɪð lɪsnɪŋ tə ɪt ðiz deɪz. noʊbəlz ɑɹ ɔl ɪkspɛktəd tə noʊ ði oʊl tʌŋ, bʌt mɛni oʊnli lɝn ɪnʌf tə ɪmpɹɛs pipəl u doʊnt. tʃɹænzleɪʃənz doʊn əv ðə seɪm saʊnd, ənlɛs ðəɹ ɪn haɪ tʃænt, ən səmtaɪmz ðət tʃeɪnʒəz minɪŋz ivən mɔɹ ðən moʊs tʃɹænzleɪʃənz. ðəɹ ɪz wʌn vɝs ɪn ðə saɪkəl - ɪt dʌzn skæn wɛl, tʃɹænzleɪɾəd wɝd fəɹ wɝd, bʌt ðɛɹz noʊ minɪŋ lɔst - ðət ɡoʊz laɪk ðɪs.

"In the great libraries," Thom said slowly. "Any number of translations, and even in the Old Tongue, here and there." Rand started to ask if there was any way for him to find one, but the gleeman went on. "The Old Tongue has music in it, but too many even of the nobles are impatient with listening to it these days. Nobles are all expected to know the Old Tongue, but many only learn enough to impress people who don't. Translations don't have the same sound, unless they're in High Chant, and sometimes that changes meanings even more than most translations. There is one verse in the Cycle - it doesn't scan well, translated word for word, but there's no meaning lost - that goes like this.

"twaɪs ən twaɪs ʃæl i bi mɑɹkt, twaɪs tə lɪv, ən twaɪs tə daɪ.

"Twice and twice shall he be marked, twice to live, and twice to die.

wʌns ðə hɛɹən, tə sɛɾ ɪz pæθ.

Once the heron, to set his path.

twaɪs ðə hɛɹən, tə neɪm ɪm tʃɹu.

Twice the heron, to name him true.

wʌns ðə dʒɹæɡən, fəɹ ɹimɛmbɹəns lɔst.

Once the Dragon, for remembrance lost.

twaɪs ðə dʒɹæɡən, fəɹ ðə pɹaɪs i mʌs peɪ."

Twice the Dragon, for the price he must pay."

hi ɹitʃt aʊɾ ən tʌtʃt ðə hɛɹənz ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɑn ɹændz haɪ kɑlɝ.

He reached out and touched the herons embroidered on Rand's high collar.

fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ɹænd kəɾ oʊnli ɡeɪp ət hɪm, ən wən i kəd spik, hɪz vɔɪs wɑz ənstɛɾi. "ðə sɔɹd meɪks faɪv. hɪlt, skæbɝd, ən bleɪd." hi tɝn ɪz hæn daʊn ɑn ðə teɪbəl, haɪɾɪŋ ðə bɹæn ɑn ɪz pɑm. fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm sɪns səlinz sɑv hæd dʌn ɪts wɝk, hi kəd fil ɪt. nɑt hɝɾɪŋ, bʌɾ i nu ɪt wɑz ðɛɹ.

For a moment, Rand could only gape at him, and when he could speak, his voice was unsteady. "The sword makes five. Hilt, scabbard, and blade." He turned his hand down on the table, hiding the brand on his palm. For the first time since Selene's salve had done its work, he could feel it. Not hurting, but he knew it was there.

"soʊ ðeɪ du." tɑm bɑɹkt ə læf. "ðɛɹz ənʌðɝ kʌmz tə maɪnd.

"So they do." Thom barked a laugh. "There's another comes to mind.

"twaɪs dɔnz ðə deɪ wən ɪz blʌɾ ɪz ʃɛd.

"Twice dawns the day when his blood is shed.

wʌns fəɹ mɔɹnɪŋ, wʌns fəɹ bɝθ.

Once for mourning, once for birth.

ɹɛɾ ɑn blæk, ðə dʒɹæɡənz blʌd steɪnz ðə ɹɑk ə ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl.

Red on black, the Dragon's blood stains the rock of Shayol Ghul.

ɪn ðə pɪɾ ə dum ʃæl ɪz blʌd fɹi mɛn fɹəm ðə ʃædoʊ."

In the Pit of Doom shall his blood free men from the Shadow."

ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, dɪnaɪɪŋ, bʌt tɑm sim nɑt tə noʊɾəs. "aɪ doʊn si haʊ ə deɪ kən dɔn twaɪs, bʌt ðən ə lɑɾ ʌv ɪt dʌzn ɹɪli meɪk mʌtʃ sɛns. ðə stoʊn ə tiɹ wɪl nɛvɝ fɔl tɪl kælændɝ ɪz wildɪd baɪ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, bʌt ðə sɔɹd ðət kænɑt bi tʌtʃt laɪz ɪn ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə stoʊn, soʊ haʊ kən i wild ɪt fɝst, ɛ? wɛl, bi ðəɾ əz ɪt meɪ. aɪ səspɛkt ɛɛs sədaɪ wəd wɑnə meɪk ɪvɛns fɪt ðə pɹɑfəsiz əz kloʊsli əz ðeɪ kæn. daɪɪŋ sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ðə blæstəd lænz wəd bi ə haɪ pɹaɪs tə peɪ fəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ əlɔŋ wɪð ðɛm."

Rand shook his head, denying, but Thom seemed not to notice. "I don't see how a day can dawn twice, but then a lot of it doesn't really make much sense. The Stone of Tear will never fall till Callandor is wielded by the Dragon Reborn, but the Sword That Cannot Be Touched lies in the Heart of the Stone, so how can he wield it first, eh? Well, be that as it may. I suspect Aes Sedai would want to make events fit the Prophecies as closely as they can. Dying somewhere in the Blasted Lands would be a high price to pay for going along with them."

ɪt wɑz ən ɛfɝt fəɹ ɹænd tə meɪk ɪz vɔɪs kɑm, bʌɾ i dɪɾ ɪt. "noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑɹ juzɪŋ mi fəɹ ɛniθɪŋ. aɪ toʊl ju, ðə læst aɪ sɔ ʌv mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz ɪn ʃaɪnɝ. ʃi sɛɾ aɪ kəd ɡoʊ wɛɹ aɪ wɑntəd, ən aɪ lɛft."

It was an effort for Rand to make his voice calm, but he did it. "No Aes Sedai are using me for anything. I told you, the last I saw of Moiraine was in Shienar. She said I could go where I wanted, and I left."

"æn ðɛɹz noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪð jə naʊ? nʌn əɾ ɔl?"

"And there's no Aes Sedai with you now? None at all?"

"nʌn."

"None."

tɑm nʌkəld ɪz dæŋɡəlɪŋ waɪt mʌstæʃɪz. hi sim sæɾəsfaɪd, ən ət ðə seɪm taɪm pʌzəld. "ðɛn waɪ æsk əbaʊt ðə pɹɑfəsiz? waɪ sɛn ði oʊɡiɝ aʊɾ ə ðə ɹum?"

Thom knuckled his dangling white mustaches. He seemed satisfied, and at the same time puzzled. "Then why ask about the Prophecies? Why send the Ogier out of the room?"

"aɪ . . . dɪdnt wɑnə əpsɛt hɪm. hiz nɝvəs ɪnʌf əbaʊt ðə hɔɹn. ðæts wʌɾ aɪ wɑntəd tə æsk. ɪz ðə hɔɹn mɛnʃən ɪn ðə - ðə pɹɑfəsiz?" hi stɪl kəd nɑt meɪk hɪmsɛlf seɪ ɪɾ ɔl ðə weɪ aʊt. "ɔl ðiz fɔls dʒɹæɡənz, ən naʊ ðə hɔɹn ɪz faʊnd. ɛvɹibɑɾi θɪŋks ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ ɪz səpoʊz tə sʌmən dɛd hɪɹoʊz tə faɪt ðə dɑɹk wʌn ɪn ðə læs bæɾəl, ən ðə . . . ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn . . . ɪz səpoʊz tə faɪt ðə dɑɹk wʌn ɪn ðə læs bæɾəl. ɪt sim nætʃɹəl ɪnʌf tə æsk."

"I . . . didn't want to upset him. He's nervous enough about the Horn. That's what I wanted to ask. Is the Horn mentioned in the - the Prophecies?" He still could not make himself say it all the way out. "All these false Dragons, and now the Horn is found. Everybody thinks the Horn of Valere is supposed to summon dead heroes to fight the Dark One in the Last Battle, and the . . . the Dragon Reborn . . . is supposed to fight the Dark One in the Last Battle. It seemed natural enough to ask."

"aɪ səpoʊz ɪɾ ɪz. nɑt mɛni noʊ ðəɾ əbaʊt ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn faɪɾɪŋ ðə læs bæɾəl, əɹ ɪf ðeɪ du, ðeɪ θɪŋk hɪl faɪɾ əlɔŋsaɪd ðə dɑɹk wʌn. nɑt mɛni ɹɛd ðə pɹɑfəsiz tə faɪn aʊt. wʌt wɑz ðət jə sɛɾ əbaʊt ðə hɔɹn? 'səpoʊz tə'?"

"I suppose it is. Not many know that about the Dragon Reborn fighting the Last Battle, or if they do, they think he'll fight alongside the Dark One. Not many read the Prophecies to find out. What was that you said about the Horn? 'Supposed to'?"

"aɪv lɝn ə fju θɪŋz sɪns wi pɑɹɾəd, tɑm. ðəl kʌm fəɹ huɛvɝ bloʊz ðə hɔɹn, ivən ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd."

"I've learned a few things since we parted, Thom. They will come for whoever blows the Horn, even a Darkfriend."

bʊʃi aɪbɹaʊz ɹoʊz nɪɹli tə tɑmz hɛɹlaɪn. "naʊ ðəɾ aɪ dɪdnt noʊ. juv lɝn ə fju θɪŋz."

Bushy eyebrows rose nearly to Thom's hairline. "Now that I didn't know. You have learned a few things."

"ɪt dʌzn min aɪ wəd lɛt ðə waɪt taʊɝ juz mi fəɹ ə fɔls dʒɹæɡən. aɪ doʊnt wɑn ɛniθɪŋ tə də wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ, əɹ fɔls dʒɹæɡənz, əɹ ðə paʊɝ, ɔɹ. . . ." ɹænd bɪɾ ɪz tʌŋ. ɡɛt mæɾ ən jə stɑɹt bæbəlɪŋ. ful!

"It doesn't mean I would let the White Tower use me for a false Dragon. I don't want anything to do with Aes Sedai, or false Dragons, or the Power, or. . . ." Rand bit his tongue. Get mad and you start babbling. Fool!

"fɔɹ ə taɪm, bɔɪ, aɪ θɔt jə wɝ ðə wʌn mɔɪɹeɪn wɑntəd, ən aɪ ivən θɔɾ aɪ nu waɪ. jə noʊ, noʊ mæn tʃuzəz tə tʃænəl ðə paʊɝ. ɪts sʌmθɪŋ ðət hæpənz tə hɪm, laɪk ə dɪziz. jə kænɑt bleɪm ə mæn fəɹ fɔlɪŋ sɪk, ivən ɪf ɪt maɪt kɪl ju, tu."

"For a time, boy, I thought you were the one Moiraine wanted, and I even thought I knew why. You know, no man chooses to channel the Power. It is something that happens to him, like a disease. You cannot blame a man for falling sick, even if it might kill you, too."

"jɔɹ nɛfju kəd tʃænəl, kʊdn hi? jə toʊl mi ðət wɑz waɪ jə hɛlpt ʌs, kəz jəɹ nɛfju hæd hæd tʃɹʌbəl wɪð ðə waɪt taʊɝ ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊbɑdi tə hɛlp hɪm. ðɛɹz oʊnli wʌn kaɪndə tʃɹʌbəl mɛn kən əv wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ."

"Your nephew could channel, couldn't he? You told me that was why you helped us, because your nephew had had trouble with the White Tower and there was nobody to help him. There's only one kind of trouble men can have with Aes Sedai."

tɑm stʌɾid ðə teɪbəltɑp, pɝsɪŋ ɪz lɪps. "aɪ doʊn səpoʊz ðəɹ ɪz ɛni jus ɪn dɪnaɪɪŋ ɪt. jə ʌndɝstænd, ɪts nɑt ðə kaɪndə θɪŋ ə mæn tɔks əbaʊt, hævɪŋ ə meɪl ɹɛləɾɪv u kəd tʃænəl. ɑɡ! ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ nɛvɝ ɡeɪv oʊɪn ə tʃæns. ðeɪ dʒɛntəl hɪm, ən ðən i daɪd. hi dʒʌst ɡeɪv ʌp wɑntɪŋ tə lɪv. . . ." hi ɛksheɪl sædli.

Thom studied the tabletop, pursing his lips. "I don't suppose there is any use in denying it. You understand, it is not the kind of thing a man talks about, having a male relative who could channel. Aaagh! The Red Ajah never gave Owyn a chance. They gentled him, and then he died. He just gave up wanting to live. . . ." He exhaled sadly.

ɹænd ʃɪvɝd. waɪ dɪdn mɔɪɹeɪn də ðət tə mi? "ə tʃæns, tɑm? dʒju min ðəɹ wɑz səm weɪ hi cʊɾə dɛlt wɪð ɪt? nɑt ɡɔn mæd? nɑt daɪd?"

Rand shivered. Why didn't Moiraine do that to me? "A chance, Thom? Do you mean there was some way he could have dealt with it? Not gone mad? Not died?"

"oʊɪn hɛld ɪɾ ɔf ɔlmoʊs θɹi jɪɹz. hi nɛvɝ hɝɾ ɛniwʌn. hi dɪdn juz ðə paʊɝ ənlɛs i hæd tə, ən ðən oʊnli tə hɛlp ɪz vɪlədʒ. hi. . . ." tɑm θɹu ʌp ɪz hænz. "aɪ səpoʊz ðəɹ wɑz noʊ tʃɔɪs. ðə pipəl wɛɹ i lɪv toʊl mi hi wɑz æktɪŋ stʃɹeɪnʒ ðət hoʊl læs jɪɹ. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt mʌtʃ wɑnə tɔk əbaʊɾ ɪt, ən ðeɪ nɪɹli stoʊn mi wən ðeɪ faʊn aʊɾ aɪ wɑz ɪz ʌŋkəl. aɪ səpoʊz i wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ mæd. bʌɾ i wɑz maɪ blʌd, bɔɪ. aɪ kæn lʌv ði ɛɛs sədaɪ fəɹ wʌt ðeɪ dɪd tə hɪm, ivən ɪf ðeɪ hæd tə. ɪf mɔɪɹeɪnz lɛt jə ɡoʊ, ðən jə ɑɹ wɛl aʊɾ ʌv ɪt."

"Owyn held it off almost three years. He never hurt anyone. He didn't use the Power unless he had to, and then only to help his village. He. . . ." Thom threw up his hands. "I suppose there was no choice. The people where he lived told me he was acting strange that whole last year. They did not much want to talk about it, and they nearly stoned me when they found out I was his uncle. I suppose he was going mad. But he was my blood, boy. I can't love the Aes Sedai for what they did to him, even if they had to. If Moiraine's let you go, then you are well out of it."

fəɹ ə moʊmən ɹænd wɑz saɪlənt. ful! ʌv kɔɹs ðɛɹz noʊ weɪ tə dil wɪð ɪt. jəɹ gɑnə ɡoʊ mæɾ ən daɪ wʌtɛvɝ jə du. bʌt bælzəmən sɛd -  "noʊ!" hi kʌlɝɾ ʌndɝ tɑmz skɹuɾəni. "aɪ min . . . aɪm aʊɾ ʌv ɪt, tɑm. bʌɾ aɪ stɪl əv ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ. θɪŋk ʌv ɪt, tɑm. ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ. ʌðɝ ɡlimən maɪt tɛl teɪlz əbaʊɾ ɪt, bʌt jə kəd seɪ jə hæɾ ɪɾ ɪn jəɹ hænz." hi ɹilaɪzd i saʊndəd laɪk səlin, bʌɾ ɔl ðət dɪd wɑz meɪk ɪm wʌndɝ wɛɹ ʃi wɑz. "ðɛɹz noʊbɑdi aɪd ɹæðɝ əv wɪð əs ðən ju, tɑm."

For a moment Rand was silent. Fool! Of course there's no way to deal with it. You're going to go mad and die whatever you do. But Ba'alzamon said -  "No!" He colored under Thom's scrutiny. "I mean . . . I am out of it, Thom. But I still have the Horn of Valere. Think of it, Thom. The Horn of Valere. Other gleemen might tell tales about it, but you could say you had it in your hands." He realized he sounded like Selene, but all that did was make him wonder where she was. "There's nobody I'd rather have with us than you, Thom."

tɑm fɹaʊn əz ɪf kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ɪt, bʌɾ ɪn ði ɛn i ʃʊk ɪz hɛd fɝmli. "bɔɪ, aɪ laɪk jə wɛl ɪnʌf, bʌt jə noʊ əz wɛl əz aɪ də ðəɾ aɪ oʊnli hɛlp bɪfɔɹ kəz ðəɹ wɑz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ mɪkst ɪn ɪt. sihæn dʌzn tʃɹaɪ tə tʃit mi mɔɹ ðən aɪ ɪkspɛkt, ən wɪð ðə kɪŋz ɡɪft æɾəd ɪn, aɪ kəd nɛvɝ ɝn əz mʌtʃ ɪn ðə vɪlədʒəz. tə maɪ vɛɹi ɡɹeɪt sɝpɹaɪz, dinə simz tə lʌv mi, ən - əz mʌtʃ ə sɝpɹaɪz - aɪ ɹɪtɝn ðə filɪŋ. naʊ, waɪ ʃəɾ aɪ liv ðət tə ɡoʊ bi tʃeɪs baɪ tʃɹɑləks ən dɑɹkfɹɛnz? ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ? oʊ, ɪts ə tɛmteɪʃən, əl ədmɪt, bʌt noʊ. noʊ, əl nɑt ɡɛt mɪkst ʌp ɪn ɪɾ əɡɛn."

Thom frowned as if considering it, but in the end he shook his head firmly. "Boy, I like you well enough, but you know as well as I do that I only helped before because there was an Aes Sedai mixed in it. Seaghan doesn't try to cheat me more than I expect, and with the King's Gift added in, I could never earn as much in the villages. To my very great surprise, Dena seems to love me, and - as much a surprise - I return the feeling. Now, why should I leave that to go be chased by Trollocs and Darkfriends? The Horn of Valere? Oh, it is a temptation, I'll admit, but no. No, I will not get mixed up in it again."

hi lin oʊvɝ tə pɪk ʌp wʌn ə ðə wʊɾən ɪnstʃɹəmən keɪsəz, lɔŋ ən nɛɹoʊ. wən i oʊpən ɪt, ə flut leɪ ɪnsaɪd, pleɪnli meɪd bʌt maʊntəd wɪð sɪlvɝ. hi kloʊzd ɪɾ əɡɛn ən slɪɾ ɪɾ əkɹɔs ðə teɪbəl. "ju maɪt nid tə ɝn jəɹ sʌpɝ əɡɛn sʌmdeɪ, bɔɪ."

He leaned over to pick up one of the wooden instrument cases, long and narrow. When he opened it, a flute lay inside, plainly made but mounted with silver. He closed it again and slid it across the table. "You might need to earn your supper again someday, boy."

"aɪ maɪɾ ət ðæt," ɹænd sɛd. "æt list wi kən tɔk. əl bi ɪn - "

"I might at that," Rand said. "At least we can talk. I will be in - "

ðə ɡlimən wɑz ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd. "ə klin bɹeɪk ɪz bɛst, bɔɪ. ɪf jəɹ ɔlweɪz kʌmɪŋ ɝaʊnd, ivən ɪf jə nɛvɝ mɛnʃən ɪt, aɪ woʊn bi eɪbəl tə ɡɛt ðə hɔɹn aʊɾ ə maɪ hɛd. ən aɪ woʊn bi tæŋɡəld ɪn ɪt. aɪ woʊnt."

The gleeman was shaking his head. "A clean break is best, boy. If you're always coming around, even if you never mention it, I won't be able to get the Horn out of my head. And I won't be tangled in it. I won't."

æftɝ ɹænd lɛft, tɑm θɹu hɪz kloʊk ɑn ðə bɛɾ ən sæt wɪð ɪz ɛlboʊz ɑn ðə teɪbəl. ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ. haʊ dɪd ðət fɑɹmbɔɪ faɪnd. . . . hi ʃʌɾ ɔf ðət laɪn ə θɔt. θɪŋk əbaʊt ðə hɔɹn tu lɔŋ, ən i wəd faɪn hɪmsɛlf ɹʌnɪŋ ɔf wɪð ɹænd tə kæɹi ɪt tə ʃaɪnɝ. ðət wəd meɪk ə stɔɹi, kæɹiɪŋ ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ tə ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz wɪð tʃɹɑləks ən dɑɹkfɹɛnz pɝsuɪŋ. skaʊlɪŋ, hi ɹimaɪndəd hɪmsɛlf ə dinə. ivən ɪf ʃi hæd nɑt lʌv hɪm, tælən sətʃ əz hɝz wɑz nɑt tə bi faʊn ɛvɹi deɪ. ən ʃi dɪd lʌv, ivən ɪf i kəd nɑt bɪɡɪn tə ɪmædʒən waɪ.

After Rand left, Thom threw his cloak on the bed and sat with his elbows on the table. The Horn of Valere. How did that farmboy find. . . . He shut off that line of thought. Think about the Horn too long, and he would find himself running off with Rand to carry it to Shienar. That would make a story, carrying the Horn of Valere to the Borderlands with Trollocs and Darkfriends pursuing. Scowling, he reminded himself of Dena. Even if she had not loved him, talent such as hers was not to be found every day. And she did love, even if he could not begin to imagine why.

"oʊl ful," hi mʌɾɝd.

"Old fool," he muttered.

"aɪ, ən oʊl ful," zɛɹə sɛd fɹəm ðə dɔɹ. hi ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt; hi hæd bɪn soʊ əbzɔɹbd ɪn ɪz θɔts ðəɾ i hæd nɑt hɝd ðə dɔɹ oʊpən. hi hæd noʊn zɛɹə fəɹ jɪɹz, ɔf ən ɑn ɪn ɪz wɑndɝɪŋz, ən ʃi ɔlweɪz tʊk fʊl ædvæntɪdʒ ə ðə fɹɛndʃɪp tə spik əɹ maɪnd. "æn oʊl ful huz pleɪɪŋ ðə ɡeɪm ə haʊsəz əɡɛn. ənlɛs maɪ ɪɹz ɑɹ feɪlɪŋ, ðət jʌŋ lɔɹɾ əz ðə saʊn ʌv ændɝ ɑn ɪz tʌŋ. hiz noʊ kɛɹhinɪn, ðæts fəɹ sɝɾən ʃʊɹ. deɪz deɪmɑɹ ɪz deɪnʒɝəs ɪnʌf wɪθaʊt lɛɾɪŋ ən aʊtlæn lɔɹd mɪks jə ɪn ɪz skimz."

"Aye, an old fool," Zera said from the door. He gave a start; he had been so absorbed in his thoughts that he had not heard the door open. He had known Zera for years, off and on in his wanderings, and she always took full advantage of the friendship to speak her mind. "An old fool who's playing the Game of Houses again. Unless my ears are failing, that young lord has the sound of Andor on his tongue. He's no Cairhienin, that's for certain sure. Daes Dae'mar is dangerous enough without letting an outland lord mix you in his schemes."

tɑm blɪŋkt, ðən kənsɪɾɝd ðə weɪ ɹænd hæd lʊkt. ðət koʊt hæd ʃʊɹli bɪn faɪn ɪnʌf fəɹ ə lɔɹd. hi wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ oʊld, lɛɾɪŋ θɪŋz laɪk ðət slɪp baɪ hɪm. ɹufəli, hi ɹilaɪzd i wɑz kənsɪɾɝɪŋ wɛðɝ tə tɛl zɛɹə ðə tʃɹuθ əɹ lɛɾ əɹ kəntɪnju θɪŋkɪŋ əz ʃi dɪd. ɔl ɪt teɪks ɪz tə θɪŋk əbaʊt ðə ɡɹeɪt ɡeɪm, ən aɪ stɑɹt pleɪɪŋ ɪt. "ðə bɔɪ ɪz ə ʃɛpɝd, zɛɹə, fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz."

Thom blinked, then considered the way Rand had looked. That coat had surely been fine enough for a lord. He was growing old, letting things like that slip by him. Ruefully, he realized he was considering whether to tell Zera the truth or let her continue thinking as she did. All it takes is to think about the Great Game, and I start playing it. "The boy is a shepherd, Zera, from the Two Rivers."

ʃi læf skɔɹnfəli. "æn ɪm ðə kwin ʌv ɡildən. aɪ tɛl ju, ðə ɡeɪm əz ɡɹoʊn deɪnʒɝəs ɪn kɛɹhin ðə læs fju jɪɹz. nʌθɪŋ laɪk wʌt jə nu ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. ðəɹ ɑɹ mɝɾɝz dʌn, naʊ. jəl əv jəɹ θɹoʊt kʌt fəɹ ju, ɪf jə doʊnt wɑtʃ aʊt."

She laughed scornfully. "And I'm the Queen of Ghealdan. I tell you, the Game has grown dangerous in Cairhien the last few years. Nothing like what you knew in Caemlyn. There are murders done, now. You'll have your throat cut for you, if you don't watch out."

"aɪ tɛl ju, aɪm nɑɾ ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪt ɡeɪm ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. ðæts ɔl twɛnti jɪɹz ɪn ðə pæst, nɪɹ ɪnʌf."

"I tell you, I am not in the Great Game any longer. That's all twenty years in the past, near enough."

"aɪ." ʃi dɪd nɑt saʊn əz ɪf ʃi bɪlivd ɪt. "bʌt bi ðəɾ əz ɪt meɪ, ən jʌŋ aʊtlæn lɔɹdz əsaɪd, juv bɪɡʌn pɝfɔɹmɪŋ ət ðə lɔɹdz' mænɝz."

"Aye." She did not sound as if she believed it. "But be that as it may, and young outland lords aside, you've begun performing at the lords' manors."

"ðeɪ peɪ wɛl."

"They pay well."

"æn ðəl pʊl jə ɪndə ðɛɹ plɑts əz sun əz ðeɪ si haʊ. ðeɪ si ə mæn, ən θɪŋk haʊ tə juz hɪm, əz nætʃɹəli əz bɹiðɪŋ. ðɪs jʌŋ lɔɹɾ ə jʊɹz woʊn hɛlp ju; ðəl iɾ ɪm əlaɪv."

"And they'll pull you into their plots as soon as they see how. They see a man, and think how to use him, as naturally as breathing. This young lord of yours won't help you; they will eat him alive."

hi ɡeɪv ʌp ɑn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kənvɪns əɹ i wɑz aʊɾ ʌv ɪt. "ɪz ðət wʌt jə keɪm ʌp tə seɪ, zɛɹə?"

He gave up on trying to convince her he was out of it. "Is that what you came up to say, Zera?"

"aɪ. fɝɡɛt pleɪɪŋ ðə ɡɹeɪt ɡeɪm, tɑm. mɛɹi dinə. ʃɪl teɪk ju, ðə mɔɹ ful hɝ, boʊni ən waɪt-hɛɹɾ əz jə ɑɹ. mɛɹi hɝ, ən fɝɡɛt ðɪs jʌŋ lɔɹɾ ən deɪz deɪmɑɹ."

"Aye. Forget playing the Great Game, Thom. Marry Dena. She'll take you, the more fool her, bony and white-haired as you are. Marry her, and forget this young lord and Daes Dae'mar."

"aɪ θæŋk jə fəɹ ði ædvaɪs," hi sɛd dʒɹaɪli. mɛɹi hɝ? bɝɾən əɹ wɪð ən oʊl hʌzbənd. ʃɪl nɛvɝ bi ə bɑɹd wɪð maɪ pæs hæŋɪŋ ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk. "ɪf jə doʊn maɪnd, zɛɹə, aɪ wɑnə bi əloʊn fəɹ ə waɪl. aɪ pɝfɔɹm fəɹ leɪɾi ɑɹɪlɪn ən əɹ ɡɛsts tənaɪt, ən aɪ nid tə pɹipɛɹ."

"I thank you for the advice," he said dryly. Marry her? Burden her with an old husband. She'll never be a bard with my past hanging around her neck. "If you don't mind, Zera, I want to be alone for a while. I perform for Lady Arilyn and her guests tonight, and I need to prepare."

ʃi ɡeɪv ɪm ə snɔɹɾ ən ə ʃeɪk ə hɝ hɛɾ ən bæŋ ðə dɔɹ ʃʌt bɪhaɪn hɝ.

She gave him a snort and a shake of her head and banged the door shut behind her.

tɑm dʒɹʌmd ɪz fɪŋɡɝz ɑn ðə teɪbəl. koʊɾ əɹ noʊ koʊt, ɹænd wɑz stɪl oʊnli ə ʃɛpɝd. ɪf i hæd bɪn mɔɹ, ɪf i hæd bɪn wʌt tɑm wʌns səspɛktəd - ə mæn u kəd tʃænəl - niðɝ mɔɪɹeɪn nɔɹ ɛni ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ wəɾ ɛvɝ əv lɛɾ ɪm wɔk əweɪ ʌnʒəntəld. hɔɹn əɹ noʊ hɔɹn, ðə bɔɪ wɑz oʊnli ə ʃɛpɝd.

Thom drummed his fingers on the table. Coat or no coat, Rand was still only a shepherd. If he had been more, if he had been what Thom once suspected - a man who could channel - neither Moiraine nor any other Aes Sedai would ever have let him walk away ungentled. Horn or no Horn, the boy was only a shepherd.

"hi ɪz aʊɾ ʌv ɪt," hi sɛɾ əlaʊd, "æn soʊ æm aɪ."

"He is out of it," he said aloud, "and so am I."


tʃæptɝ twɛntisɛvən


CHAPTER 27

ðə ʃædoʊ ɪn ðə naɪt


The Shadow in the Night

"aɪ də nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ɪt," lɔɪəl sɛd. "aɪ wɑz wɪnɪŋ, moʊst ə ðə taɪm. ən ðən dinə keɪm ɪn ən dʒɔɪn ðə ɡeɪm, ən ʃi wʌn ɪɾ ɔl ɹaɪt bæk. ɛvɹi tɔs. ʃi kɔld ɪɾ ə lɪɾəl lɛsən. wʌd ʃi min baɪ ðæt?"

"I do not understand it," Loial said. "I was winning, most of the time. And then Dena came in and joined the game, and she won it all right back. Every toss. She called it a little lesson. What did she mean by that?"

ɹænd ən ði oʊɡiɝ wɝ meɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ weɪ θɹu ðə fɔɹɡeɪt, ðə bʌntʃ ʌv ɡɹeɪps bɪhaɪn ðɛm. ðə sʌn sæt loʊ ɪn ðə wɛst, ə ɹɛd bɔl hæf bɪloʊ ðə hɝaɪzən, θɹoʊɪŋ lɔŋ ʃædoʊz bɪhaɪn ðɛm. ðə stʃɹit wɑz ɛmpti seɪv fəɹ wʌn ə ðə bɪɡ pʌpəts, ə ɡoʊt-hɔɹn tʃɹɑlɑk wɪð ə sɔɹɾ əɾ ɪts bɛlt, kʌmɪŋ təwɔɹɾ əm wɪð faɪv mɛn wɝkɪŋ ðə poʊlz, bʌt saʊnz ə mɛɹəmən dʒɹɪftəd stɪl fɹəm ʌðɝ pɑɹts ə ðə fɔɹɡeɪt, wɛɹ ðə hɔlz ʌv ɛntɝteɪnmən ən ðə tævɝnz stʊd. hɪɹ, dɔɹz wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi bɑɹɾ ən wɪndoʊz ʃʌɾɝd.

Rand and the Ogier were making their way through the Foregate, The Bunch of Grapes behind them. The sun sat low in the west, a red ball half below the horizon, throwing long shadows behind them. The street was empty save for one of the big puppets, a goat-horned Trolloc with a sword at its belt, coming toward them with five men working the poles, but sounds of merriment drifted still from other parts of the Foregate, where the halls of entertainment and the taverns stood. Here, doors were already barred and windows shuttered.

ɹænd stɑp fɪŋɡɝɪŋ ðə wʊɾən flut keɪs ən slʌŋ ɪɾ ɑn ɪz bæk. aɪ səpoʊz aɪ kʊdn ɪkspɛkt ɪm tə θɹoʊ oʊvɝ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ən kʌm wɪð mi, bʌɾ ət list i kəd tɔk tə mi. laɪt, aɪ wɪʃ ɪŋtʃɹ wəd ʃoʊ ʌp. hi stʌft ɪz hænz ɪn ɪz pɑkəts ən fɛl səlinz noʊt.

Rand stopped fingering the wooden flute case and slung it on his back. I suppose I couldn't expect him to throw over everything and come with me, but at least he could talk to me. Light, I wish Ingtar would show up. He stuffed his hands in his pockets and felt Selene's note.

"ju doʊn səpoʊz ʃi. . . ." lɔɪəl pɔzd ənkʌmftəbli. "ju doʊn səpoʊz ʃi tʃiɾəd, də ju? ɛvɹibɑɾi wɑz ɡɹɪnɪŋ əz ɪf ʃi wɝ duɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ klɛvɝ."

"You don't suppose she. . . ." Loial paused uncomfortably. "You don't suppose she cheated, do you? Everybody was grinning as if she were doing something clever."

ɹænd ʃɹʌɡd əɾ ɪz kloʊk. aɪ hæv tə teɪk ðə hɔɹn ən ɡoʊ. ɪf wi weɪt fəɹ ɪŋtʃɹ, ɛniθɪŋ kən hæpən. feɪn wɪl kʌm sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ. aɪ hæv tə steɪ əhɛɾ ə hɪm. ðə mɛn wɪð ðə pʌpət wɝ ɔlmoʊs tə ðɛm.

Rand shrugged at his cloak. I have to take the Horn and go. If we wait for Ingtar, anything can happen. Fain will come sooner or later. I have to stay ahead of him. The men with the puppet were almost to them.

"ɹænd," lɔɪəl sɛd sʌɾənli, "aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðæts ə - "

"Rand," Loial said suddenly, "I don't think that's a - "

əbɹʌpli ðə mɛn lɛt ðɛɹ poʊlz klæɾɝ tə ðə pæk dɝt stʃɹit; ɪnstɛɾ ə kəlæpsɪŋ, ðə tʃɹɑlɑk lɛp fəɹ ɹænd wɪð aʊtstʃɹɛtʃt hænz.

Abruptly the men let their poles clatter to the packed dirt street; instead of collapsing, the Trolloc leaped for Rand with outstretched hands.

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ taɪm tə θɪŋk. ɪnstɪŋk bɹɔt ðə sɔɹɾ aʊɾ ʌv ɪts ʃiθ ɪn ə flæʃɪŋ ɑɹk. ðə mun ɹaɪzəz oʊvɝ ðə leɪks. ðə tʃɹɑlɑk stæɡɝd bæk wɪð ə bʌbəlɪŋ kɹaɪ, snɑɹlɪŋ ivən əz ɪt fɛl.

There was no time to think. Instinct brought the sword out of its sheath in a flashing arc. The Moon Rises Over the Lakes. The Trolloc staggered back with a bubbling cry, snarling even as it fell.

fəɹ ən ɪnstən ɛvɹiwʌn stʊd fɹoʊzən. ðən ðə mɛn - ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz, ðeɪ hæd tə bi - lʊk fɹəm ðə tʃɹɑlɑk laɪɪŋ ɪn ðə stʃɹit tə ɹænd, wɪð ðə sɔɹɾ ɪn ɪz hænz ən lɔɪəl əɾ ɪz saɪd. ðeɪ tɝn ən ɹæn.

For an instant everyone stood frozen. Then the men - the Darkfriends, they had to be - looked from the Trolloc lying in the street to Rand, with the sword in his hands and Loial at his side. They turned and ran.

ɹænd wɑz stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə tʃɹɑlɑk, tu. ðə vɔɪd hæd sɝaʊndəɾ ɪm bɪfɔɹ ɪz hæn tʌtʃt hɪlt; seɪɾɪn ʃoʊn ɪn ɪz maɪnd, bɛkənɪŋ, sɪkənɪŋ. wɪð ən ɛfɝt, hi meɪd ðə vɔɪd vænɪʃ, ən lɪkt ɪz lɪps. wɪθaʊt ði ɛmptinəs, fɪɹ kɹɔld ɑn ɪz skɪn.

Rand was staring at the Trolloc, too. The void had surrounded him before his hand touched hilt; saidin shone in his mind, beckoning, sickening. With an effort, he made the void vanish, and licked his lips. Without the emptiness, fear crawled on his skin.

"lɔɪəl, wɪv tə ɡɛt bæk tə ði ɪn. hʊɹɪnz əloʊn, ən ðeɪ - " hi ɡɹʌntɪɾ əz i wɑz lɪftəɾ ɪndə ði ɛɹ baɪ ə θɪk ɑɹm lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə pɪn boʊθ ə hɪz tə hɪz tʃɛst. ə hɛɹi hænd ɡɹæbd ɪz θɹoʊt. hi kɑt saɪɾ ʌv ə tʌsk snaʊt dʒʌst oʊvɝ ɪz hɛd. ə ɹæŋk smɛl fɪld ɪz noʊz, ikwəl pɑɹts saʊɝ swɛɾ ən pɪɡsti.

"Loial, we have to get back to the inn. Hurin's alone, and they - " He grunted as he was lifted into the air by a thick arm long enough to pin both of his to his chest. A hairy hand grabbed his throat. He caught sight of a tusked snout just over his head. A rank smell filled his nose, equal parts sour sweat and pigsty.

əz kwɪkli əz ɪt hæd siz hɪm, ðə hæn əɾ ɪz θɹoʊt wɑz tɔɹn əweɪ. stʌnd, ɹænd stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪt, ət ðə θɪk oʊɡiɝ fɪŋɡɝz klʌtʃɪŋ ðə tʃɹɑlɑks ɹɪst.

As quickly as it had seized him, the hand at his throat was torn away. Stunned, Rand stared at it, at the thick Ogier fingers clutching the Trolloc's wrist.

"hoʊld ɑn, ɹænd." lɔɪəlz vɔɪs saʊndəd stʃɹeɪnd. ði oʊɡiɝz ʌðɝ hæn keɪm ɝaʊn ən tʊk hoʊld ə ði ɑɹm stɪl hoʊldɪŋ ɹænd əbʌv ðə ɡɹaʊnd. "hoʊld ɑn."

"Hold on, Rand." Loial's voice sounded strained. The Ogier's other hand came around and took hold of the arm still holding Rand above the ground. "Hold on."

ɹænd wɑz ʃeɪkən fɹəm saɪd tə saɪɾ əz oʊɡiɝ ən tʃɹɑlɑk stʃɹʌɡəld. əbɹʌpli hi fɛl fɹi. stæɡɝɪŋ, hi tʊk tu stɛps tə ɡɛt klɪɹ ən tɝn bæk wɪð sɔɹd ɹeɪzd.

Rand was shaken from side to side as Ogier and Trolloc struggled. Abruptly he fell free. Staggering, he took two steps to get clear and turned back with sword raised.

stændɪŋ bɪhaɪn ðə bɔɹ-snaʊɾəd tʃɹɑlɑk, lɔɪəl hæɾ ɪt baɪ ɹɪst ən fɔɹɑɹm, hoʊldɪŋ ɪts ɑɹmz spɹɛd waɪd, bɹiðɪŋ hɑɹd wɪð ði ɛfɝt. ðə tʃɹɑlɑk snɑɹəld ɡʌtʃɝəli ɪn ðə hɑɹʃ tʃɹɑlɑk tʌŋ, θɹoʊɪŋ ɪts hɛd bæk ɪn ɛfɝts tə kætʃ lɔɪəl wɪð ə tʌsk. ðɛɹ buts skʌfəld əkɹɔs ðə dɝɾ ə ðə stʃɹit.

Standing behind the boar-snouted Trolloc, Loial had it by wrist and forearm, holding its arms spread wide, breathing hard with the effort. The Trolloc snarled gutturally in the harsh Trolloc tongue, throwing its head back in efforts to catch Loial with a tusk. Their boots scuffled across the dirt of the street.

ɹænd tʃɹaɪd tə faɪn ə pleɪs tə pʊɾ ɪz bleɪɾ ɪn ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɪθaʊt hɝɾɪŋ lɔɪəl, bʌɾ oʊɡiɝ ən tʃɹɑlɑk spʌn ɪn ðɛɹ ɹʌf dæns soʊ mʌtʃ ðəɾ i kəd faɪnd noʊ oʊpənɪŋ.

Rand tried to find a place to put his blade in the Trolloc without hurting Loial, but Ogier and Trolloc spun in their rough dance so much that he could find no opening.

wɪð ə ɡɹʌnt, ðə tʃɹɑlɑk pʊld ɪts lɛft ɑɹm fɹi, bʌt bɪfɔɹ ɪt kəd lus ɪtsɛlf kəmplitli, lɔɪəl snæpt ɪz oʊn ɑɹm ɝaʊn ɪts nɛk, hʌɡɪŋ ðə kɹitʃɝ kloʊz. ðə tʃɹɑlɑk klɔɾ əɾ ɪts sɔɹd; ðə saɪð-laɪk bleɪd hʌŋ ɑn ðə ɹɔŋ saɪd fəɹ lɛft-hændəd jus, bʌɾ ɪntʃ baɪ ɪntʃ ðə dɑɹk stil bɪɡæn slaɪɾɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə skæbɝd. ən stɪl ðeɪ θɹæʃt əbaʊt soʊ ðət ɹænd kəd nɑt stʃɹaɪk wɪθaʊt ɹɪskɪŋ lɔɪəl.

With a grunt, the Trolloc pulled its left arm free, but before it could loose itself completely, Loial snapped his own arm around its neck, hugging the creature close. The Trolloc clawed at its sword; the scythe-like blade hung on the wrong side for left-handed use, but inch by inch the dark steel began sliding out of the scabbard. And still they thrashed about so that Rand could not strike without risking Loial.

ðə paʊɝ. ðət kəd də ɪt. haʊ, hi dɪd nɑt noʊ, bʌɾ i nu nʌθɪŋ ɛls tə tʃɹaɪ. ðə tʃɹɑlɑk hæɾ ɪts sɔɹd hæf ənʃiðd. wən ðə kɝv bleɪd wɑz bɛɹ, ɪt wəd kɪl lɔɪəl.

The Power. That could do it. How, he did not know, but he knew nothing else to try. The Trolloc had its sword half unsheathed. When the curved blade was bare, it would kill Loial.

ɹɪlʌktənli, ɹænd fɔɹm ðə vɔɪd. seɪɾɪn ʃoʊn ət hɪm, pʊld ət hɪm. dɪmli, hi sim tə ɹikɔl ə taɪm wən ɪt hæd sʌŋ tə hɪm, bʌt naʊ ɪɾ oʊnli dʒɹu hɪm, ə flaʊɝz pɝfjum dʒɹɔɪŋ ə bi, ə mɪɾənz stɛntʃ dʒɹɔɪŋ ə flaɪ. hi oʊpən hɪmsɛlf ʌp, ɹitʃt fəɹ ɪt. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ ðɛɹ. hi kəɾ əz wɛl əv bɪn ɹitʃɪŋ fəɹ laɪɾ ɪn tʃɹuθ. ðə teɪn slɪɾ ɔf ɑntu hɪm, sɔɪlɪŋ hɪm, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ floʊ ʌv laɪɾ ɪnsaɪd hɪm. dʒɹɪvən baɪ ə dɪstən dɛspɝeɪʃən, hi tʃɹaɪɾ əɡɛn ən əɡɛn. ən əɡɛn ən əɡɛn ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli ðə teɪnt.

Reluctantly, Rand formed the void. Saidin shone at him, pulled at him. Dimly, he seemed to recall a time when it had sung to him, but now it only drew him, a flower's perfume drawing a bee, a midden's stench drawing a fly. He opened himself up, reached for it. There was nothing there. He could as well have been reaching for light in truth. The taint slid off onto him, soiling him, but there was no flow of light inside him. Driven by a distant desperation, he tried again and again. And again and again there was only the taint.

wɪð ə sʌɾən hiv, lɔɪəl θɹu ðə tʃɹɑlɑk əsaɪd, soʊ hɑɹd ðət ðə θɪŋ kɑɹtwild əɡɛns ðə saɪɾ ʌv ə bɪldɪŋ. ɪt stʃɹʌk, hɛdfɝst, wɪð ə laʊd kɹæk, ən slɪd daʊn ðə wɔl tə laɪ wɪð ɪts nɛk twɪstəɾ əɾ ən ɪmpɑsəbəl æŋɡəl. lɔɪəl stʊd stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪt, hɪz tʃɛs hivɪŋ.

With a sudden heave, Loial threw the Trolloc aside, so hard that the thing cartwheeled against the side of a building. It struck, headfirst, with a loud crack, and slid down the wall to lie with its neck twisted at an impossible angle. Loial stood staring at it, his chest heaving.

ɹænd lʊkt aʊɾ ə ði ɛmptinəs fəɹ ə moʊmən bɪfɔɹ i ɹilaɪzd wʌt hæd hæpənd. əz sun əz i dɪd, ðoʊ, hi lɛt vɔɪɾ ən teɪntɪd laɪt ɡoʊ, ən hɝid tə lɔɪəlz saɪd.

Rand looked out of the emptiness for a moment before he realized what had happened. As soon as he did, though, he let void and tainted light go, and hurried to Loial's side.

"aɪ nɛvɝ . . . kɪl bɪfɔɹ, ɹænd." lɔɪəl dʒɹu ə ʃʌɾɝɪŋ bɹɛθ.

"I never . . . killed before, Rand." Loial drew a shuddering breath.

"ɪt wʊɾə kɪl jə ɪf jə hædnt," ɹænd toʊl hɪm. æŋkʃəsli, hi lʊkt ət ði æliz ən ʃʌɾɝd wɪndoʊz ən bɑɹd dɔɹz. wɛɹ ðəɹ wɝ tu tʃɹɑləks, ðəɹ hæd tə bi mɔɹ. "ɪm sɑɹi jə hæd tə də ɪt, lɔɪəl, bʌɾ ɪt wʊɾə kɪl boʊθ ʌv ʌs, əɹ wɝs."

"It would have killed you if you hadn't," Rand told him. Anxiously, he looked at the alleys and shuttered windows and barred doors. Where there were two Trollocs, there had to be more. "I'm sorry you had to do it, Loial, but it would have killed both of us, or worse."

"aɪ noʊ. bʌɾ aɪ kænɑt laɪk ɪt. ivən ə tʃɹɑlɑk." pɔɪntɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə sɛɾɪŋ sʌn, ði oʊɡiɝ sizd ɹændz ɑɹm. "ðɛɹz ənʌðɝ ə ðɛm."

"I know. But I cannot like it. Even a Trolloc." Pointing toward the setting sun, the Ogier seized Rand's arm. "There's another of them."

əɡɛns ðə sʌn, ɹænd kəd nɑt meɪk aʊt dɪteɪlz, bʌɾ ɪɾ əpɪɹd tə bi ənʌðɝ ɡɹup ə mɛn wɪð ə hjudʒ pʌpət, kʌmɪŋ təwɔɹd lɔɪəl ən hɪm. ɪksɛp ðət naʊ hi nu wʌt tə lʊk fɔɹ, ðə "pʌpət" muvd ɪts lɛɡz tu nætʃɹəli, ən ðə snaʊɾəd hɛd ɹoʊz tə snɪf ði ɛɹ wɪθaʊɾ ɛniwʌn lɪftɪŋ ə poʊl. hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ðə tʃɹɑlɑk ən dɑɹkfɹɛnz kəd si hɪm əmʌŋ ði ivnɪŋ ʃædoʊz, əɹ wʌt leɪ ɪn ðə stʃɹiɾ ɝaʊn hɪm; ðeɪ muv tu sloʊli fəɹ ðæt. jɛɾ ɪt wɑz pleɪn ðeɪ wɝ hʌntɪŋ, ən kʌmɪŋ kloʊsɝ.

Against the sun, Rand could not make out details, but it appeared to be another group of men with a huge puppet, coming toward Loial and him. Except that now he knew what to look for, the "puppet" moved its legs too naturally, and the snouted head rose to sniff the air without anyone lifting a pole. He did not think the Trolloc and Darkfriends could see him among the evening shadows, or what lay in the street around him; they moved too slowly for that. Yet it was plain they were hunting, and coming closer.

"feɪn noʊz aɪm aʊt hɪɹ sʌmwɛɹ," hi sɛd, heɪstəli waɪpɪŋ ɪz bleɪɾ ɑn ə dɛd tʃɹɑlɑks koʊt. "hiz sɛɾ əm tə faɪn mi. hiz əfɹeɪɾ ə ðə tʃɹɑləks biɪŋ sin, ðoʊ, əɹ i wʊdn əv əm dɪsɡaɪzd. ɪf wi kən ɹitʃ ə stʃɹit wɛɹ ðəɹ ɑɹ pipəl, wɪl bi seɪf. wɪv tə ɡɛt bæk tə hʊɹɪn. ɪf feɪn faɪnz hɪm, əloʊn wɪð ðə hɔɹn. . . ."

"Fain knows I am out here somewhere," he said, hastily wiping his blade on a dead Trolloc's coat. "He's set them to find me. He is afraid of the Trollocs being seen, though, or he wouldn't have them disguised. If we can reach a street where there are people, we'll be safe. We have to get back to Hurin. If Fain finds him, alone with the Horn. . . ."

hi pʊld lɔɪəl əlɔŋ tə ðə nɛks kɔɹnɝ ən tɝn təwɔɹd ðə nɪɹəst saʊnz ə læftɝ ən mjuzɪk, bʌt lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ ɹitʃt ɪt, ənʌðɝ ɡɹup ə mɛn əpɪɹɾ əhɛɾ ə ðɛm ɪn ði ʌðɝwaɪz ɛmpti stʃɹit wɪð ə pʌpət ðət wɑz noʊ pʌpət. ɹænd ən lɔɪəl tʊk ðə nɛks tɝnɪŋ. ɪt lɛɾ ist.

He pulled Loial along to the next corner and turned toward the nearest sounds of laughter and music, but long before they reached it, another group of men appeared ahead of them in the otherwise empty street with a puppet that was no puppet. Rand and Loial took the next turning. It led east.

ɛvɹi taɪm ɹænd tʃɹaɪd tə ɹitʃ ðə mjuzɪk ən læftɝ, ðəɹ wɑz ə tʃɹɑlɑk ɪn ðə weɪ, ɔfən snɪfɪŋ ði ɛɹ fəɹ ə sɛnt. səm tʃɹɑləks hʌntəd baɪ sɛnt. səmtaɪmz, hɪɹ wɛɹ ðəɹ wɝ noʊ aɪz tə si, ə tʃɹɑlɑk stɔkt əloʊn. mɔɹ ðən wʌns i wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz wʌn i hæd sin bɪfɔɹ. ðeɪ wɝ kloʊzɪŋ ɪn, ən meɪkɪŋ ʃʊɹ i ən lɔɪəl dɪd nɑt liv ðə dɪzɝɾɪd stʃɹits wɪð ðɛɹ ʃʌɾɝd wɪndoʊz. sloʊli ðə tu ʌv əm wɝ fɔɹst ist, əweɪ fɹəm ðə sɪɾi ən hʊɹɪn, əweɪ fɹəm ʌðɝ pipəl, əlɔŋ nɛɹoʊ, sloʊli dɑɹkənɪŋ stʃɹits ðət ɹæn ɪn ɔl dɝɛkʃənz, ʌphɪl ən daʊn. ɹænd aɪd ðə haʊsəz ðeɪ pæst, ðə tɔl bɪldɪŋz kloʊzd ʌp taɪt fəɹ ðə naɪt, wɪð mɔɹ ðən ə lɪɾəl ɹəɡɹɛt. ivən ɪf i paʊndɪɾ ɑn ə dɔɹ əntɪl sʌmwʌn oʊpən ɪt, ivən ɪf ðeɪ tʊk lɔɪəl ən ɪm ɪn, nʌn ə ðə dɔɹz i sɔ wəd stɑp ə tʃɹɑlɑk. ɔl ðət wəd də wəd bi tə ɔfɝ ʌp mɔɹ vɪktəmz wɪð lɔɪəl ən hɪmsɛlf.

Every time Rand tried to reach the music and laughter, there was a Trolloc in the way, often sniffing the air for a scent. Some Trollocs hunted by scent. Sometimes, here where there were no eyes to see, a Trolloc stalked alone. More than once he was sure it was one he had seen before. They were closing in, and making sure he and Loial did not leave the deserted streets with their shuttered windows. Slowly the two of them were forced east, away from the city and Hurin, away from other people, along narrow, slowly darkening streets that ran in all directions, uphill and down. Rand eyed the houses they passed, the tall buildings closed up tight for the night, with more than a little regret. Even if he pounded on a door until someone opened it, even if they took Loial and him in, none of the doors he saw would stop a Trolloc. All that would do would be to offer up more victims with Loial and himself.

"ɹænd," lɔɪəl sɛd faɪnəli, "ðɛɹ ɪz noʊwɛɹ ɛls tə ɡoʊ."

"Rand," Loial said finally, "there is nowhere else to go."

ðeɪ hæd ɹitʃt ði istɝn ɛdʒ ə ðə fɔɹɡeɪt; ðə tɔl bɪldɪŋz tə iðɝ saɪɾ ə ðɛm wɝ ðə læst. laɪts ɪn wɪndoʊz ɑn ði ʌpɝ stɔɹiz mɑk hɪm, bʌt ðə loʊɝ flɔɹz wɝ ɔl ʃʌt taɪt. əhɛd leɪ ðə hɪlz, kloʊkt ɪn fɝs twaɪlaɪɾ ən bɛɹ ə soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə fɑɹmhaʊs. nɑɾ ɪntaɪɝli ɛmpti, ðoʊ. hi kəd dʒʌs meɪk aʊt peɪl wɔlz sɝaʊndɪŋ wʌn ə ðə lɑɹdʒɝ hɪlz, pɝhæps ə maɪl əweɪ, ən bɪldɪŋz ɪnsaɪd.

They had reached the eastern edge of the Foregate; the tall buildings to either side of them were the last. Lights in windows on the upper stories mocked him, but the lower floors were all shut tight. Ahead lay the hills, cloaked in first twilight and bare of so much as a farmhouse. Not entirely empty, though. He could just make out pale walls surrounding one of the larger hills, perhaps a mile away, and buildings inside.

"wʌns ðeɪ pʊʃ əs aʊt ðɛɹ," lɔɪəl sɛd, "ðeɪ woʊn əv tə wɝi hu siz ðɛm."

"Once they push us out there," Loial said, "they won't have to worry who sees them."

ɹænd dʒɛstʃɝd tə ðə wɔlz ɝaʊn ðə hɪl. "ðoʊz ʃəd stɑp ə tʃɹɑlɑk. ɪt mʌs bi ə lɔɹdz mænɝ. meɪbi ðəl lɛɾ əs ɪn. ən oʊɡiɝ, ən ən aʊtlæn lɔɹd? ðɪs koʊɾ əz tə bi ɡʊd fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ." hi lʊk bæk daʊn ðə stʃɹit. noʊ tʃɹɑləks ɪn saɪt jɛt, bʌɾ i dʒɹu lɔɪəl ɝaʊn ðə saɪɾ ə ðə bɪldɪŋ ɛniweɪ.

Rand gestured to the walls around the hill. "Those should stop a Trolloc. It must be a lord's manner. Maybe they'll let us in. An Ogier, and an outland lord? This coat has to be good for something sooner or later." He looked back down the street. No Trollocs in sight yet, but he drew Loial around the side of the building anyway.

"aɪ θɪŋk ðəɾ ɪz ði ɪluməneɪɾɝz' tʃæptɝ haʊs, ɹænd. ɪluməneɪɾɝz ɡɑɹd ðɛɹ sikɹəts taɪtli. aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðeɪ wəd lɛt ɡɔlʒɹiən hɪmsɛlf ɪnsaɪd ðɛɹ."

"I think that is the Illuminators' chapter house, Rand. Illuminators guard their secrets tightly. I don't think they would let Galldrian himself inside there."

"wʌt tʃɹʌbəl əv jə ɡɑɾən jɝsɛlf ɪndə naʊ?" sɛɾ ə fəmɪljɝ wʊmənz vɔɪs. ðəɹ wɑz sʌɾənli ə spaɪsi pɝfjum ɪn ði ɛɹ.

"What trouble have you gotten yourself into now?" said a familiar woman's voice. There was suddenly a spicy perfume in the air.

ɹænd stɛɹd: səlin stɛpt ɝaʊn ðə kɔɹnɝ ðeɪ hæd dʒʌst ɹaʊndəd, hɝ waɪt dʒɹɛs bɹaɪɾ ɪn ðə dɪmnəs. "haʊ dɪd jə ɡɛt hɪɹ? wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ hɪɹ? juv tə liv ɪmiɾiətli. ɹʌn! ðəɹ ɑɹ tʃɹɑləks æftɝ ʌs."

Rand stared: Selene stepped around the corner they had just rounded, her white dress bright in the dimness. "How did you get here? What are you doing here? You have to leave immediately. Run! There are Trollocs after us."

"soʊ aɪ sɔ." hɝ vɔɪs wɑz dʒɹaɪ, jɛt kul ən kəmpoʊzd. "aɪ keɪm tə faɪn ju, ən aɪ faɪn jə əlaʊɪŋ tʃɹɑləks tə hɝd jə laɪk ʃip. kən ðə mæn u pəzɛsəz ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ lɛt hɪmsɛlf bi tʃɹiɾəd soʊ?"

"So I saw." Her voice was dry, yet cool and composed. "I came to find you, and I find you allowing Trollocs to herd you like sheep. Can the man who possesses the Horn of Valere let himself be treated so?"

"aɪ doʊn əv ɪt wɪð mi," hi snæpt, "æn aɪ doʊnt noʊ haʊ ɪt kəd hɛlp ɪf aɪ dɪd. ðə dɛd hɪɹoʊz ɑɹ nɑt səpoʊz tə kʌm bæk tə seɪv mi fɹəm tʃɹɑləks. səlin, juv tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ. naʊ!" hi pɪɹɾ ɝaʊn ðə kɔɹnɝ.

"I don't have it with me," he snapped, "and I don't know how it could help if I did. The dead heroes are not supposed to come back to save me from Trollocs. Selene, you have to get away. Now!" He peered around the corner.

nɑt mɔɹ ðən ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz əweɪ, ə tʃɹɑlɑk wɑz stɪkɪŋ ɪts hɔɹn hɛd kɔʃəsli ɪndə ðə stʃɹit, smɛlɪŋ ðə naɪt. ə lɑɹdʒ ʃædoʊ baɪ ɪts saɪd hæd tə bi ənʌðɝ tʃɹɑlɑk, ən ðəɹ wɝ smɔlɝ ʃædoʊz, tu. dɑɹkfɹɛnz.

Not more than a hundred paces away, a Trolloc was sticking its horned head cautiously into the street, smelling the night. A large shadow by its side had to be another Trolloc, and there were smaller shadows, too. Darkfriends.

"tu leɪt," ɹænd mʌɾɝd. hi ʃɪftəd ðə flut keɪs tə pʊl ɔf ɪz kloʊk ən ɹæp ɪɾ ɝaʊn hɝ. ɪt wɑz lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə haɪɾ əɹ waɪt dʒɹɛs ɪntaɪɝli, ən tʃɹeɪl ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪsaɪdz. "jul əv tə hoʊl ðəɾ ʌp tə ɹʌn," hi toʊl hɝ. "lɔɪəl, ɪf ðeɪ woʊn lɛɾ əs ɪn, wɪl əv tə faɪn ə weɪ tə snik ɪn."

"Too late," Rand muttered. He shifted the flute case to pull off his cloak and wrap it around her. It was long enough to hide her white dress entirely, and trail on the ground besides. "You'll have to hold that up to run," he told her. "Loial, if they won't let us in, we will have to find a way to sneak in."

"bʌt, ɹænd - "

"But, Rand - "

"wʊd jə ɹæðɝ weɪt fəɹ ðə tʃɹɑləks?" hi ɡeɪv lɔɪəl ə pʊʃ tə stɑɹt hɪm, ən tʊk səlinz hæn tə fɑloʊ əɾ ə tʃɹɑt. "faɪn əs ə pæθ ðət woʊn bɹeɪk əɹ nɛks, lɔɪəl."

"Would you rather wait for the Trollocs?" He gave Loial a push to start him, and took Selene's hand to follow at a trot. "Find us a path that won't break our necks, Loial."

"jɔɹ lɛɾɪŋ jɝsɛlf bɪkʌm flʌstɝd," səlin sɛd. ʃi sim tə hæv lɛs tʃɹʌbəl fɑloʊɪŋ lɔɪəl ɪn ðə feɪlɪŋ laɪt ðən ɹænd dɪd. "sik ðə wʌnnəs, ən bi kɑm. wʌn u wəd bi ɡɹeɪt mʌst ɔlweɪz bi kɑm."

"You're letting yourself become flustered," Selene said. She seemed to have less trouble following Loial in the failing light than Rand did. "Seek the Oneness, and be calm. One who would be great must always be calm."

"ðə tʃɹɑləks maɪt hɪɹ ju," hi toʊl hɝ. "aɪ doʊnt wɑnt ɡɹeɪtnəs." hi θɔɾ i hɝɾ ən ɪɹəteɪɾəd ɡɹʌn fɹəm hɝ.

"The Trollocs might hear you," he told her. "I don't want greatness." He thought he heard an irritated grunt from her.

stoʊnz səmtaɪmz tɝn ʌndɝfʊt, bʌt ðə weɪ əkɹɔs ðə hɪlz wɑz nɑt hɑɹd dɪspaɪt ðə twaɪlaɪt ʃædoʊz. tʃɹiz, ən ivən bɹʌʃ, hæd lɔŋ sɪns bɪn klɪɹd fɹəm ðə hɪlz fəɹ faɪɝwʊd. nʌθɪŋ ɡɹu ɪksɛp ni-haɪ ɡɹæs ðət ɹʌsəl sɔfli ɝaʊn ðɛɹ lɛɡz. ə naɪt bɹiz keɪm ʌp sɔfli. ɹænd wɝid ðəɾ ɪt maɪt kæɹi ðɛɹ sɛn tə ðə tʃɹɑləks.

Stones sometimes turned underfoot, but the way across the hills was not hard despite the twilight shadows. Trees, and even brush, had long since been cleared from the hills for firewood. Nothing grew except knee-high grass that rustled softly around their legs. A night breeze came up softly. Rand worried that it might carry their scent to the Trollocs.

lɔɪəl stɑpt wən ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə wɔl; ɪt stʊd twaɪs əz haɪ əz ði oʊɡiɝ, ðə stoʊnz kʌvɝd wɪð ə waɪɾɪʃ plæstɝ. ɹænd pɪɹd bæk təwɔɹd ðə fɔɹɡeɪt. bænz ə laɪɾəd wɪndoʊz ɹitʃt aʊt laɪk spoʊks ʌv ə wil fɹəm ðə sɪɾi wɔlz.

Loial stopped when they reached the wall; it stood twice as high as the Ogier, the stones covered with a whitish plaster. Rand peered back toward the Foregate. Bands of lighted windows reached out like spokes of a wheel from the city walls.

"lɔɪəl," hi sɛd sɔfli, "kæn jə si ðɛm? ɑɹ ðeɪ fɑloʊɪŋ ʌs?"

"Loial," he said softly, "can you see them? Are they following us?"

ði oʊɡiɝ lʊkt ɪn ðə dɝɛkʃən ə ðə fɔɹɡeɪt, ən nɑɾəd ənhæpəli. "aɪ oʊnli si səm ə ðə tʃɹɑləks, bʌt ðeɪ ɑɹ kʌmɪŋ ðɪs weɪ. ɹʌnɪŋ. ɹænd, aɪ ɹɪli doʊn θɪŋk - "

The Ogier looked in the direction of the Foregate, and nodded unhappily. "I only see some of the Trollocs, but they are coming this way. Running. Rand, I really don't think - "

səlin kʌɾ ɪm ɔf. "ɪf i wɑns tə ɡoʊ ɪn, ælɑntɪn, hi nidz ə dɔɹ. sətʃ əz ðət wʌn." ʃi pɔɪntəd tə ə dɑɹk pætʃ ə lɪɾəl daʊn ðə wɔl. ivən wɪð əɹ tɛlɪŋ hɪm, ɹænd wɑz nɑt sɝɾən ɪt wɑz ə dɔɹ, bʌt wən ʃi stʃɹoʊd tə ɪɾ ən pʊld, ɪɾ oʊpənd.

Selene cut him off. "If he wants to go in, alantin, he needs a door. Such as that one." She pointed to a dark patch a little down the wall. Even with her telling him, Rand was not certain it was a door, but when she strode to it and pulled, it opened.

"ɹænd," lɔɪəl bɪɡæn.

"Rand," Loial began.

ɹænd pʊʃt ɪm tə ðə dɔɹ. "leɪɾɝ, lɔɪəl. ən sɔfli. wɝ haɪɾɪŋ, ɹɪmɛmbɝ?" hi ɡɑɾ əm ɪnsaɪɾ ən kloʊz ðə dɔɹ bɪhaɪn ðɛm. ðəɹ wɝ bɹækəts fəɹ ə bɑɹ, bʌt noʊ bɑɹ tə bi sin. ɪt wəd nɑt stɑp ɛniwʌn, bʌt meɪbi ðə tʃɹɑləks wəd hɛzəteɪt tə kʌm ɪnsaɪd ðə wɔlz.

Rand pushed him to the door. "Later, Loial. And softly. We're hiding, remember?" He got them inside and closed the door behind them. There were brackets for a bar, but no bar to be seen. It would not stop anyone, but maybe the Trollocs would hesitate to come inside the walls.

ðeɪ wɝ ɪn ən æliweɪ liɾɪŋ ʌp ðə hɪl bɪtwin tu lɔŋ, loʊ wɪndoʊləs bɪldɪŋz. ət fɝst i θɔt ðeɪ wɝ stoʊn, tu, bʌt ðən i ɹilaɪz ðə waɪt plæstɝ hæd bɪn leɪɾ oʊvɝ wʊd. ɪt wɑz dɑɹk ɪnʌf naʊ fəɹ ðə mun ɹəflɛktɪŋ fɹəm ðə wɔlz tə ɡɪv ə sɛmbləns ə laɪt.

They were in an alleyway leading up the hill between two long, low windowless buildings. At first he thought they were stone, too, but then he realized the white plaster had been laid over wood. It was dark enough now for the moon reflecting from the walls to give a semblance of light.

"bɛɾɝ tə bi ɝɛstəd baɪ ði ɪluməneɪɾɝz ðən teɪkən baɪ tʃɹɑləks," hi mɝmɝd, stɑɹɾɪŋ ʌp ðə hɪl.

"Better to be arrested by the Illuminators than taken by Trollocs," he murmured, starting up the hill.

"bʌt ðəɾ ɪz wʌɾ aɪ wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə tɛl ju," lɔɪəl pɹətɛstəd. "aɪv hɝd ði ɪluməneɪɾɝz kɪl ɪntʃɹuɾɝz. ðeɪ kip ðɛɹ sikɹəts hɑɹɾ ən fæst, ɹænd."

"But that is what I was trying to tell you," Loial protested. "I've heard the Illuminators kill intruders. They keep their secrets hard and fast, Rand."

ɹænd stɑp dɛɾ ən stɛɹd bæk ət ðə dɔɹ. ðə tʃɹɑləks wɝ stɪl aʊt ðɛɹ. ət ðə wɝst, hjumənz hæd tə bi bɛɾɝ tə dil wɪð ðən tʃɹɑləks. hi maɪt bi eɪbəl tə tɔk ði ɪluməneɪɾɝz ɪndə lɛɾɪŋ əm ɡoʊ; tʃɹɑləks dɪd nɑt lɪsən bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ kɪld. "aɪm sɑɹi aɪ ɡɑt jə ɪndə ðɪs, səlin."

Rand stopped dead and stared back at the door. The Trollocs were still out there. At the worst, humans had to be better to deal with than Trollocs. He might be able to talk the Illuminators into letting them go; Trollocs did not listen before they killed. "I'm sorry I got you into this, Selene."

"deɪnʒɝ ædz ə sɝɾən sʌmθɪŋ," ʃi sɛd sɔfli. "æn soʊ fɑɹ, jə hændəl ɪt wɛl. ʃæl wi si wʌt wi faɪnd?" ʃi bɹʌʃt pæst ɪm ʌp ði æliweɪ. ɹænd fɑloʊd, ðə spaɪsi smɛl ə hɝ fɪlɪŋ ɪz nɑstʃɹəlz.

"Danger adds a certain something," she said softly. "And so far, you handle it well. Shall we see what we find?" She brushed past him up the alleyway. Rand followed, the spicy smell of her filling his nostrils.

ətɑp ðə hɪl, ði æliweɪ oʊpən ɑntu ə waɪɾ ɪkspæns ə smuðli flæɾənd kleɪ, ɔlmoʊst əz peɪl əz ðə plæstɝ ən nɪɹli sɝaʊndəd baɪ mɔɹ waɪt, wɪndoʊləs bɪldɪŋz wɪð ðə ʃædoʊz ə nɛɹoʊ æliz bɪtwin, bʌt tə ɹændz ɹaɪt stʊd wʌn bɪldɪŋ wɪð wɪndoʊz, laɪt fɔlɪŋ ɑntu ðə peɪl kleɪ. hi pʊl bæk ɪndə ðə ʃædoʊz ə ði æli əz ə mæn ən ə wʊmən əpɪɹd, wɔkɪŋ sloʊli əkɹɔs ði oʊpən speɪs.

Atop the hill, the alleyway opened onto a wide expanse of smoothly flattened clay, almost as pale as the plaster and nearly surrounded by more white, windowless buildings with the shadows of narrow alleys between, but to Rand's right stood one building with windows, light falling onto the pale clay. He pulled back into the shadows of the alley as a man and a woman appeared, walking slowly across the open space.

ðɛɹ kloʊðz wɝ sɝɾənli nɑt kɛɹhinɪn. ðə mæn wɔɹ bɹitʃɪz əz bæɡi əz ɪz ʃɝt slivz, boʊθ ɪn ə sɑf jɛloʊ, wɪð ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi ɑn ðə lɛɡz ə hɪz bɹitʃɪz ən əkɹɔs ðə tʃɛst ə hɪz ʃɝt. ðə wʊmənz dʒɹɛs, wɝkt ɪlæbɹətli əkɹɔs ðə bɹɛst, simd ə peɪl ɡɹin, ən əɹ hɛɹ wɑz dʌn ɪn ə mʌltətuɾ ə ʃɔɹt bɹeɪdz.

Their clothes were certainly not Cairhienin. The man wore breeches as baggy as his shirt sleeves, both in a soft yellow, with embroidery on the legs of his breeches and across the chest of his shirt. The woman's dress, worked elaborately across the breast, seemed a pale green, and her hair was done in a multitude of short braids.

"ɔl ɪz ɪn ɹɛɾinəs, jə seɪ?" ðə wʊmən dɪmændəd. "ju ɑɹ sɝɾən, tɑmuz? ɔl?"

"All is in readiness, you say?" the woman demanded. "You are certain, Tammuz? All?"

ðə mæn spɹɛɾ ɪz hænz. "ɔlweɪz jə tʃɛk bɪhaɪn mi, ɑlʌdʒɹə. ɔl ɪz ɪn ɹɛɾinəs. ðə dɪspleɪ, ɪt kəd bi ɡɪvən ðɪs vɛɹi moʊmənt."

The man spread his hands. "Always you check behind me, Aludra. All is in readiness. The display, it could be given this very moment."

"ðə ɡeɪts ən dɔɹz, ðeɪ ɑɹ ɔl bɑɹd? ɔl ə ðə . . . ?" hɝ vɔɪs feɪɾəd əz ðeɪ muvd ɑn tə ðə fɑɹ ɛn ə ðə laɪɾəd bɪldɪŋ.

"The gates and doors, they are all barred? All of the . . . ?" Her voice faded as they moved on to the far end of the lighted building.

ɹænd stʌɾid ði oʊpən ɛɹiə, ɹɛkəɡnaɪzɪŋ ɔlmoʊs nʌθɪŋ. ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ɪt, sɛvɹəl dʌzən əpɹaɪt tubz, itʃ nɪɹli əz tɔl əz i ən ə fʊɾ əɹ mɔɹ əkɹɔs, sæɾ ɑn lɑɹdʒ wʊɾən beɪsəz. fɹəm itʃ tub, ə dɑɹk, twɪstəd kɔɹd ɹæn əkɹɔs ðə ɡɹaʊn ən bɪhaɪn ə loʊ wɔl, pɝhæps θɹi peɪsɪz lɔŋ, ɑn ðə fɑɹ saɪd. ɔl ɝaʊn ði oʊpən speɪs stʊɾ ə wɛltɝ ʌv wʊɾən ɹæks wɪð tʃɹɔfs ən tubz ən fɔɹk stɪks ən ə skɔɹ ʌv ʌðɝ θɪŋz.

Rand studied the open area, recognizing almost nothing. In the middle of it, several dozen upright tubes, each nearly as tall as he and a foot or more across, sat on large wooden bases. From each tube, a dark, twisted cord ran across the ground and behind a low wall, perhaps three paces long, on the far side. All around the open space stood a welter of wooden racks with troughs and tubes and forked sticks and a score of other things.

ɔl ðə faɪɹwɝks i hæɾ ɛvɝ sin kəd bi hɛld ɪn wʌn hænd, ən ðət wɑz əz mʌtʃ əz i nu, ɪksɛp ðət ðeɪ bɝst wɪð ə ɡɹeɪt ɹɔɹ, əɹ wɪzd əlɔŋ ðə ɡɹaʊn ɪn spaɪɹəlz ə spɑɹks, əɹ səmtaɪmz ʃɑɾ ɪndə ði ɛɹ. ðeɪ ɔlweɪz keɪm wɪð wɔɹnɪŋz fɹəm ði ɪluməneɪɾɝz ðəɾ oʊpənɪŋ wʌn kəd kɑz ɪt tə ɡoʊ ɔf. ɪn ɛni keɪs, faɪɹwɝks wɝ tu ɪkspɛnsɪv fəɹ ðə vɪlədʒ kaʊnsəl tə hæv əlaʊɾ ɛnibəɾi ənskɪl tə oʊpən wʌn. hi kəd wɛl ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə taɪm wən mæt hæd tʃɹaɪd tə də dʒʌs ðæt; ɪt wɑz nɪɹli ə wik bɪfɔɹ ɛniwʌn bʌt mæts oʊn mʌðɝ wəd spik tə hɪm. ði oʊnli θɪŋ ðət ɹænd faʊn fəmɪljɝ əɾ ɔl wɑz ðə kɔɹdz - ðə fjuzəz. ðæt, hi nu, wɑz wɛɹ jə sɛt ðə faɪɝ.

All the fireworks he had ever seen could be held in one hand, and that was as much as he knew, except that they burst with a great roar, or whizzed along the ground in spirals of sparks, or sometimes shot into the air. They always came with warnings from the Illuminators that opening one could cause it to go off. In any case, fireworks were too expensive for the Village Council to have allowed anybody unskilled to open one. He could well remember the time when Mat had tried to do just that; it was nearly a week before anyone but Mat's own mother would speak to him. The only thing that Rand found familiar at all was the cords - the fuses. That, he knew, was where you set the fire.

wɪð ə ɡlæns bæk ət ði ənbæɹɹd dɔɹ, hi moʊʃən ði ʌðɝz tə fɑloʊ ən stɑɹɾəd ɝaʊn ðə tubz. ɪf ðeɪ wɝ gɑnə faɪn ə pleɪs tə haɪd, hi wɑntəd tə bi əz fɑɹ fɹəm ðət dɔɹ əz i kʊd.

With a glance back at the unbarred door, he motioned the others to follow and started around the tubes. If they were going to find a place to hide, he wanted to be as far from that door as he could.

ɪt mɛn meɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ weɪ bɪtwin ðə ɹæks, ən ɹænd hɛld ɪz bɹɛθ ɛvɹi taɪm i bɹʌʃt əɡɛnst wʌn. ðə θɪŋz ɪn əm ʃɪftəd wɪð ðə slaɪɾəst tʌtʃ, ɹætlɪŋ. ɔl ə ðɛm sim tə bi meɪɾ ʌv wʊd, wɪθaʊɾ ə pis ə mɛɾəl. hi kəɾ ɪmædʒən ðə ɹækɪɾ ɪf wʌn wɝ nɑkt oʊvɝ. hi aɪd ðə tɔl tubz wɛɹəli, ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ðə bæŋ meɪd baɪ wʌn ðə saɪz ə hɪz fɪŋɡɝ. ɪf ðoʊz wɝ faɪɹwɝks, hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə bi ðɪs kloʊs tə ðɛm.

It meant making their way between the racks, and Rand held his breath every time he brushed against one. The things in them shifted with the slightest touch, rattling. All of them seemed to be made of wood, without a piece of metal. He could imagine the racket if one were knocked over. He eyed the tall tubes warily, remembering the bang made by one the size of his finger. If those were fireworks, he did not want to be this close to them.

lɔɪəl mʌɾɝd tə hɪmsɛlf kəntɪnjuəli, ɪspɛʃli wən i bʌmpt wʌn ə ðə ɹæks, ðən stɑɹɾəd bæk soʊ fæs ðəɾ i bʌmpt ənʌðɝ. ði oʊɡiɝ kɹɛpt əlɔŋ ɪn ə klaʊɾ ə klæɾɝz ən mʌɾɝɪŋ.

Loial muttered to himself continually, especially when he bumped one of the racks, then started back so fast that he bumped another. The Ogier crept along in a cloud of clatters and muttering.

səlin wɑz noʊ lɛs ənɝvɪŋ. ʃi stʃɹoʊɾ əz kæʒəwəli əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ ɑn ə sɪɾi stʃɹit. ʃi dɪd nɑt bʌmp ɛniθɪŋ, dɪd nɑt meɪk ə saʊnd, bʌt ʃi ɔlsoʊ meɪd noʊ ɛfɝt tə kip ðə kloʊk kloʊzd. ðə waɪɾ ə hɝ dʒɹɛs sim bɹaɪɾɝ ðən ɔl ðə wɔlz təɡɛðɝ. hi pɪɹɾ ət ðə laɪɾəd wɪndoʊz, weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ sʌmwʌn tə əpɪɹ. ɔl ɪt wəd teɪk wɑz wʌn; səlin kəd nɑt feɪl tə bi sin, ði əlɑɹm ɡɪvən.

Selene was no less unnerving. She strode as casually as if they were on a city street. She did not bump anything, did not make a sound, but she also made no effort to keep the cloak closed. The white of her dress seemed brighter than all the walls together. He peered at the lighted windows, waiting for someone to appear. All it would take was one; Selene could not fail to be seen, the alarm given.

ðə wɪndoʊz ɹɪmeɪn ɛmpti, ðoʊ. ɹænd wɑz dʒʌs bɹiðɪŋ ə saɪ ʌv ɹɪlif əz ðeɪ əpɹoʊtʃt ðə loʊ wɔl - ən ði æliz ən bɪldɪŋz bɪhaɪn ɪt - wən lɔɪəl bɹʌʃt əɡɛnst ənʌðɝ ɹæk, stændɪŋ ɹaɪt bɪsaɪd ðə wɔl. ɪt hɛl tɛn sɑft-lʊkɪŋ stɪks, əz lɔŋ əz ɹændz ɑɹm, wɪð θɪn stʃɹimz ə smoʊk ɹaɪzɪŋ fɹəm ðɛɹ tɪps. ðə ɹæk meɪd hɑɹdli ə saʊnd wən ɪt fɛl, ðə smoʊldɝɪŋ stɪks spɹɔlɪŋ əkɹɔs wʌn ə ðə fjuzəz. wɪð ə kɹæklɪŋ hɪs, ðə fjuz bɝst ɪndə fleɪm, ən ðə fleɪm ɹeɪs təwɔɹd wʌn ə ðə tɔl tubz.

The windows remained empty, though. Rand was just breathing a sigh of relief as they approached the low wall - and the alleys and buildings behind it - when Loial brushed against another rack, standing right beside the wall. It held ten soft-looking sticks, as long as Rand's arm, with thin streams of smoke rising from their tips. The rack made hardly a sound when it fell, the smoldering sticks sprawling across one of the fuses. With a crackling hiss, the fuse burst into flame, and the flame raced toward one of the tall tubes.

ɹænd ɡɑɡəl fəɹ ən ɪnstənt, ðən i tʃɹaɪd tə wɪspɝ ə ʃaʊt. "bɪhaɪn ðə wɔl!"

Rand goggled for an instant, then he tried to whisper a shout. "Behind the wall!"

səlin meɪɾ ən æŋɡɹi nɔɪz wən i bɔɹ əɹ tə ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪhaɪn ðə wɔl, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt kɛɹ. hi tʃɹaɪd tə spɹɛd hɪmsɛlf oʊvɝ əɹ pɹoʊtɛktɪvli əz lɔɪəl kɹaʊɾəd bɪsaɪd ðɛm. weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ðə tub tə bɝst, hi wʌndɝɾ ɪf ðəɹ wəd bi ɛniθɪŋ lɛft ə ðə wɔl. ðəɹ wɑz ə hɑloʊ θʌmp ðəɾ i fɛl θɹu ðə ɡɹaʊn əz mʌtʃ əz hɝd. kɔʃəsli, hi lɪftəd hɪmsɛlf ɔf ə səlin ɪnʌf tə pɪɹ ɝaʊn ði ɛdʒ ə ðə wɔl. ʃi fɪstɪɾ ɪm ɪn ðə ɹɪbz, hɑɹd, ən ɹɪəld aʊt fɹəm ʌndɝ ɪm wɪð ən oʊθ ɪn ə læŋɡwədʒ i dɪd ɹɛkəɡnaɪz, bʌɾ i wɑz bɪɑnd noʊɾɪsɪŋ.

Selene made an angry noise when he bore her to the ground behind the wall, but he did not care. He tried to spread himself over her protectively as Loial crowded beside them. Waiting for the tube to burst, he wondered if there would be anything left of the wall. There was a hollow thump that he felt through the ground as much as heard. Cautiously, he lifted himself off of Selene enough to peer around the edge of the wall. She fisted him in the ribs, hard, and wriggled out from under him with an oath in a language he did recognize, but he was beyond noticing.

ə tʃɹɪkəl ə smoʊk wɑz likɪŋ fɹəm ðə tɑp ʌv wʌn ə ðə tubz. ðət wɑz ɔl. hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd wʌndɝɪŋli. ɪf ðæts ɔl ðəɹ ɪz tə ɪt. . . .

A trickle of smoke was leaking from the top of one of the tubes. That was all. He shook his head wonderingly. If that's all there is to it. . . .

wɪð ə kɹæʃ laɪk θʌndɝ, ə hjudʒ flaʊɝ ə ɹɛɾ ən waɪt blum haɪ ɪn ðə naʊ dɑɹk skaɪ, ðən sloʊli bɪɡæn dʒɹɪftɪŋ əweɪ ɪn spɑɹkəlz.

With a crash like thunder, a huge flower of red and white bloomed high in the now dark sky, then slowly began drifting away in sparkles.

əz i ɡɑɡəld əɾ ɪt, ðə laɪɾəd bɪldɪŋ ɪɹʌptəd wɪð nɔɪz. ʃaʊɾɪŋ mɛn ən wɪmən fɪl ðə wɪndoʊz, stɛɹɪŋ ən pɔɪntɪŋ.

As he goggled at it, the lighted building erupted with noise. Shouting men and women filled the windows, staring and pointing.

ɹænd lɔŋɪŋli aɪd ðə dɑɹk æliweɪ, oʊnli ə dʌzən stɛps əweɪ. ən ðə fɝst stɛp wəd bi ɪn fʊl vju ʌv ðə pipəl ət ðə wɪndoʊz. paʊndɪŋ fit pɔɹd fɹəm ðə bɪldɪŋ.

Rand longingly eyed the dark alleyway, only a dozen steps away. And the first step would be in full view of the people at the windows. Pounding feet poured from the building.

hi pɹɛs lɔɪəl ən səlin bæk əɡɛns ðə wɔl, hoʊpɪŋ ðeɪ lʊk laɪk dʒʌst ənʌðɝ ʃædoʊ. "bi stɪl ən bi saɪlənt," hi wɪspɝd. "ɪts əɹ oʊnli hoʊp."

He pressed Loial and Selene back against the wall, hoping they looked like just another shadow. "Be still and be silent," he whispered. "It's our only hope."

"səmtaɪmz," səlin sɛd kwaɪətli, "ɪf jə ɑɹ vɛɹi stɪl, noʊ wʌn kən si jə əɾ ɔl." ʃi dɪd nɑt saʊn ðə lis bɪt wɝid.

"Sometimes," Selene said quietly, "if you are very still, no one can see you at all." She did not sound the least bit worried.

buts θʌmp bæk ən fɔɹθ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə wɔl, ən vɔɪsəz wɝ ɹeɪzd ɪn æŋɡɝ. ɪspɛʃli ðə wʌn ɹænd ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd əz ɑlʌdʒɹə.

Boots thumped back and forth on the other side of the wall, and voices were raised in anger. Especially the one Rand recognized as Aludra.

"ju ɡɹeɪt bəfun, tɑmuz! jə ɡɹeɪt pɪɡ, ju! jəɹ mʌðɝ, ʃi wɑz ə ɡoʊt, tɑmuz! wʌn deɪ jəl kɪl əs ɔl."

"You great buffoon, Tammuz! You great pig, you! Your mother, she was a goat, Tammuz! One day you will kill us all."

"aɪ æm nɑt tə bleɪm fəɹ ðɪs, ɑlʌdʒɹə," ðə mæn pɹətɛstəd. "aɪ hæv bɪn ʃʊɹ tə pʊɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɛɹ ɪt bɪlɔŋd, ən ðə pʌŋks, ðeɪ wɝ - "

"I am not to blame for this, Aludra," the man protested. "I have been sure to put everything where it belonged, and the punks, they were - "

"ju wɪl nɑt spik tə mi, tɑmuz! ə ɡɹeɪt pɪɡ dʌz nɑt dɪzɝv tə spik laɪk ə hjumən!" ɑlʌdʒɹəz vɔɪs tʃeɪnʒd ɪn ænsɝ tə ənʌðɝ mænz kwɛstʃən. "ðɛɹ ɪz noʊ taɪm tə pɹipɛɹ ənʌðɝ. ɡɔlʒɹiən, hi mʌs bi sæɾəsfaɪd wɪð ðə ɹɛs fəɹ tənaɪt. ən wʌn ɝli. ən ju, tɑmuz! jəl sɛɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɹaɪt, ən təmɑɹoʊ jəl liv wɪð ðə kɑɹts tə baɪ ðə mənʊɹ. dʌz ɛniθɪŋ ɛls ɡoʊ ɹɔŋ ðɪs naɪt, əl nɑt tʃɹʌs jə əɡɛn ivən wɪð soʊ mʌtʃ əz ðə mənʊɹ!"

"You will not speak to me, Tammuz! A great pig does not deserve to speak like a human!" Aludra's voice changed in answer to another man's question. "There is no time to prepare another. Galldrian, he must be satisfied with the rest for tonight. And one early. And you, Tammuz! You will set everything right, and tomorrow you will leave with the carts to buy the manure. Does anything else go wrong this night, I will not trust you again even with so much as the manure!"

fʊtstɛps feɪɾəd bæk təwɔɹd ðə bɪldɪŋ tə ði əkʌmpnɪmən ʌv ɑlʌdʒɹəz mʌɾɝɪŋ. tɑmuz ɹɪmeɪnd, ɡɹoʊlɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ əbaʊt ði ənfɛɹnəs ʌv ɪɾ ɔl.

Footsteps faded back toward the building to the accompaniment of Aludra's muttering. Tammuz remained, growling under his breath about the unfairness of it all.

ɹænd stɑp bɹiðɪŋ əz ðə mæn keɪm oʊvɝ tə ɹaɪt ðə tɑpəl stænd. pɹɛs bæk ɪn ðə ʃædoʊz əɡɛns ðə wɔl, hi kəd si tɑmuzəz bæk ən ʃoʊldɝ. ɔl ðə mæn hæd tə də wɑz tɝn ɪz hɛd, ən i kəd nɑt mɪs siɪŋ ɹænd ən ði ʌðɝz. stɪl kəmpleɪnɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf, tɑmuz ɝeɪnʒd ðə smoʊldɝɪŋ stɪks ɪn ðə stænd, ðən stɔkt ɔf təwɔɹd ðə bɪldɪŋ wɛɹ ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls hæd ɡɔn.

Rand stopped breathing as the man came over to right the toppled stand. Pressed back in the shadows against the wall, he could see Tammuz's back and shoulder. All the man had to do was turn his head, and he could not miss seeing Rand and the others. Still complaining to himself, Tammuz arranged the smoldering sticks in the stand, then stalked off toward the building where everyone else had gone.

lɛɾɪŋ ɪz bɹɛθ ɡoʊ, ɹænd tʊk ə kwɪk lʊk æftɝ ðə mæn, ðən pʊl bæk ɪndə ðə ʃædoʊz. ə fju pipəl stɪl stʊɾ ət ðə wɪndoʊz. "wi kæn ɪkspɛkt ɛni mɔɹ lʌk tənaɪt," hi wɪspɝd.

Letting his breath go, Rand took a quick look after the man, then pulled back into the shadows. A few people still stood at the windows. "We can't expect any more luck tonight," he whispered.

"ɪɾ ɪz sɛd ɡɹeɪt mɛn meɪk ðɛɹ oʊn lʌk," səlin sɛd sɔfli.

"It is said great men make their own luck," Selene said softly.

"wɪl jə stɑp ðæt," hi toʊld əɹ wɛɹəli. hi wɪʃt ðə smɛl ə hɝ dɪd nɑt fɪl ɪz hɛd soʊ; ɪt meɪɾ ɪt hɑɹd tə θɪŋk klɪɹli. hi kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə fil ə hɝ bɑɾi wən i pʊʃt əɹ daʊn - sɔfnəs ən fɝmnəs ɪn ə dɪstɝbɪŋ blɛnd - ən ðət dɪd nɑt hɛlp iðɝ.

"Will you stop that," he told her wearily. He wished the smell of her did not fill his head so; it made it hard to think clearly. He could remember the feel of her body when he pushed her down - softness and firmness in a disturbing blend - and that did not help either.

"ɹænd?" lɔɪəl wɑz piɹɪŋ ɝaʊn ði ɛn ə ðə wɔl əweɪ fɹəm ðə laɪɾəd bɪldɪŋ. "aɪ θɪŋk wi nid səm mɔɹ lʌk, ɹænd."

"Rand?" Loial was peering around the end of the wall away from the lighted building. "I think we need some more luck, Rand."

ɹænd ʃɪftəd tə lʊk oʊvɝ ði oʊɡiɝz ʃoʊldɝ. bɪɑn oʊpən speɪs, ɪn ði æliweɪ ðət lɛd tə ðə bɑɹləs dɔɹ, θɹi tʃɹɑləks wɝ piɹɪŋ kɔʃəsli aʊɾ ə ðə ʃædoʊz təwɔɹd ðə laɪɾəd wɪndoʊz. wʌn wʊmən wɑz stændɪŋ əɾ ə wɪndoʊ; ʃi dɪd nɑt sim tə si ðə tʃɹɑləks.

Rand shifted to look over the Ogier's shoulder. Beyond open space, in the alleyway that led to the barless door, three Trollocs were peering cautiously out of the shadows toward the lighted windows. One woman was standing at a window; she did not seem to see the Trollocs.

"soʊ," səlin sɛd kwaɪətli. "ɪt bɪkʌmz ə tʃɹæp. ðiz pipəl meɪ kɪl jə ɪf ðeɪ teɪk ju. ðə tʃɹɑləks ʃʊɹli wɪl. bʌt pɝhæps jə kən sleɪ ðə tʃɹɑləks tu kwɪkli fəɹ əm tə meɪk ɛni aʊtkɹaɪ. pɝhæps jə kən stɑp ðə pipəl fɹəm kɪlɪŋ jə tə pɹəzɝv ðɛɹ lɪɾəl sikɹəts. jə meɪ nɑt wɑnt ɡɹeɪtnəs, bʌɾ ɪɾəl teɪk ə ɡɹeɪt mæn tə də ðiz θɪŋz."

"So," Selene said quietly. "It becomes a trap. These people may kill you if they take you. The Trollocs surely will. But perhaps you can slay the Trollocs too quickly for them to make any outcry. Perhaps you can stop the people from killing you to preserve their little secrets. You may not want greatness, but it will take a great man to do these things."

"ju doʊn əv tə saʊn hæpi əbaʊɾ ɪt," ɹænd sɛd. hi tʃɹaɪd tə stɑp θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt haʊ ʃi smɛld, haʊ ʃi fɛlt, ən ðə vɔɪɾ ɔlmoʊst sɝaʊndəd hɪm. hi ʃʊk ɪɾ əweɪ. ðə tʃɹɑləks dɪd nɑt sim tə hæv loʊkeɪɾəd ðɛm, jɛt. hi sɛɾəld bæk, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə nɪɹəs dɑɹk æliweɪ. wʌns ðeɪ meɪɾ ə muv təwɔɹɾ ɪt, ðə tʃɹɑləks wəd ʃʊɹli si, ən soʊ wəd ðə wʊmən ət ðə wɪndoʊ. ɪt wəd bi ə ɹeɪs əz tə wɛðɝ tʃɹɑləks əɹ ɪluməneɪɾɝz ɹitʃt əm fɝst.

"You don't have to sound happy about it," Rand said. He tried to stop thinking about how she smelled, how she felt, and the void almost surrounded him. He shook it away. The Trollocs did not seem to have located them, yet. He settled back, staring at the nearest dark alleyway. Once they made a move toward it, the Trollocs would surely see, and so would the woman at the window. It would be a race as to whether Trollocs or Illuminators reached them first.

"jɔɹ ɡɹeɪtnəs wɪl meɪk mi hæpi." dɪspaɪt ðə wɝdz, səlin saʊndəɾ æŋɡɹi. "pɝhæps aɪ ʃəd liv jə tə faɪn jəɹ oʊn weɪ fəɹ ə taɪm. ɪf jəl nɑt teɪk ɡɹeɪtnəs wən ɪts ɪn jəɹ ɡɹæsp, pɝhæps jə dɪzɝv tə daɪ."

"Your greatness will make me happy." Despite the words, Selene sounded angry. "Perhaps I should leave you to find your own way for a time. If you'll not take greatness when it is in your grasp, perhaps you deserve to die."

ɹænd ɹəfjuz tə lʊk ət hɝ. "lɔɪəl, kən jə si ɪf ðɛɹz ənʌðɝ dɔɹ daʊn ðəɾ æli?"

Rand refused to look at her. "Loial, can you see if there's another door down that alley?"

ði oʊɡiɝ ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ðɛɹ ɪz tu mʌtʃ laɪt hɪɹ ən tu mʌtʃ dɑɹk ðɛɹ. ɪf aɪ wɝ ɪn ði æli, jɛs."

The Ogier shook his head. "There is too much light here and too much dark there. If I were in the alley, yes."

ɹænd fɪŋɡɝd ðə hɪlt ə hɪz sɔɹd. "teɪk səlin. əz sun əz jə si ə dɔɹ - ɪf jə də - kɔl aʊt, ən əl fɑloʊ. ɪf ðəɹ ɪzən ə dɔɹ ət ði ɛnd, jəl əv tə lɪft əɹ soʊ ʃi kən ɹitʃ ðə tɑp ə ðə wɔl ən klaɪm oʊvɝ."

Rand fingered the hilt of his sword. "Take Selene. As soon as you see a door - if you do - call out, and I'll follow. If there isn't a door at the end, you will have to lift her so she can reach the top of the wall and climb over."

"ɔl ɹaɪt, ɹænd." lɔɪəl saʊndəd wɝid. "bʌt wən wi muv, ðoʊz tʃɹɑləks wɪl kʌm æftɝ ʌs, noʊ mæɾɝ u ɪz wɑtʃɪŋ. ivən ɪf ðəɹ ɪz ə dɔɹ, ðəl bi ɑn əɹ hilz."

"All right, Rand." Loial sounded worried. "But when we move, those Trollocs will come after us, no matter who is watching. Even if there is a door, they will be on our heels."

"ju lemi wɝi əbaʊt ðə tʃɹɑləks." θɹi ʌv ðɛm. aɪ maɪt də ɪt, wɪð ðə vɔɪd. ðə θɔɾ ə seɪɾɪn dɪsaɪɾɪd hɪm. tu mɛni stʃɹeɪnʒ θɪŋz hæd hæpənd wən i lɛt ðə meɪl hæf ə ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs kʌm kloʊs. "aɪ wɪl fɑloʊ əz sun əz aɪ kæn. ɡoʊ." hi tɝn tə pɪɹ ɝaʊn ðə wɔl ət ðə tʃɹɑləks.

"You let me worry about the Trollocs." Three of them. I might do it, with the void. The thought of saidin decided him. Too many strange things had happened when he let the male half of the True Source come close. "I will follow as soon as I can. Go." He turned to peer around the wall at the Trollocs.

fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz aɪ, hi hæɾ ən ɪmpɹɛʃən ə lɔɪəlz bʌlk muvɪŋ, ʌv səlinz waɪt dʒɹɛs, hæf kʌvɝd baɪ hɪz kloʊk. wʌn ə ðə tʃɹɑləks bɪɑn ðə tubz pɔɪntəd tə ðɛm ɪksaɪɾədli, bʌt stɪl ðə θɹi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ɡlænsɪŋ ʌp ət ðə wɪndoʊ wɛɹ ðə wʊmən stɪl wɑtʃt. θɹi ʌv ðɛm. ðəɹ əz tə bi ə weɪ. nɑt ðə vɔɪd. nɑt seɪɾɪn.

From the corner of his eye, he had an impression of Loial's bulk moving, of Selene's white dress, half covered by his cloak. One of the Trollocs beyond the tubes pointed to them excitedly, but still the three hesitated, glancing up at the window where the woman still watched. Three of them. There has to be a way. Not the void. Not saidin.

"ðɛɹ ɪz ə dɔɹ!" keɪm lɔɪəlz sɑf kɔl. wʌn ə ðə tʃɹɑləks tʊk ə stɛp aʊɾ ə ðə ʃædoʊz, ən ði ʌðɝz fɑloʊd, ɡæðɝɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz. əz fɹəm ə dɪstəns, ɹænd hɝd ðə wʊmən ət ðə wɪndoʊ kɹaɪ aʊt, ən lɔɪəl ʃaʊɾəd sʌmθɪŋ.

"There is a door!" came Loial's soft call. One of the Trollocs took a step out of the shadows, and the others followed, gathering themselves. As from a distance, Rand heard the woman at the window cry out, and Loial shouted something.

wɪθaʊt θɪŋkɪŋ, ɹænd wɑz ɑn ɪz fit. hi hæd tə stɑp ðə tʃɹɑləks sʌmhaʊ, əɹ ðeɪ wəd ɹʌn ɪm daʊn, ən lɔɪəl ən səlin. hi snætʃt wʌn ə ðə smoʊldɝɪŋ stɪks ən hɝl hɪmsɛlf ət ðə nɪɹəs tub. ɪt tɪltəd, stɑɹɾəd tə fɔl oʊvɝ, ən i kɑt ðə skwɛɹ wʊɾən beɪs; ðə tub pɔɪntəd stʃɹeɪɾ ət ðə tʃɹɑləks. ðeɪ sloʊɾ ənsɝteɪnli - ðə wʊmən ət ðə wɪndoʊ skɹimd - ən ɹænd tʌtʃt ðə smoʊkɪŋ ɛn ə ðə stɪk tə ðə fjuz ɹaɪt wɛɹ ɪt dʒɔɪn ðə tub.

Without thinking, Rand was on his feet. He had to stop the Trollocs somehow, or they would run him down, and Loial and Selene. He snatched one of the smoldering sticks and hurled himself at the nearest tube. It tilted, started to fall over, and he caught the square wooden base; the tube pointed straight at the Trollocs. They slowed uncertainly - the woman at the window screamed - and Rand touched the smoking end of the stick to the fuse right where it joined the tube.

ðə hɑloʊ θʌmp keɪm ɪmiɾiətli, ən ðə θɪk wʊɾən beɪs slæmd əɡɛns hɪm, nɑkɪŋ ɪm daʊn. ə ɹɔɹ laɪk ə θʌndɝklæp bɹoʊk ðə naɪɾ ən ə blaɪndɪŋ bɝst ə laɪt tɔɹ əweɪ ðə dɑɹk.

The hollow thump came immediately, and the thick wooden base slammed against him, knocking him down. A roar like a thunderclap broke the night and a blinding burst of light tore away the dark.

blɪŋkɪŋ, ɹænd stæɡɝd tə hɪz fit, kɑfɪŋ ɪn θɪk, ækɹɪd smoʊk, ɪɹz ɹɪŋɪŋ. hi stɛɹɾ ɪn əmeɪzmənt. hæf ðə tubz ən ɔl ə ðə ɹæks leɪ ɑn ðɛɹ saɪdz, ən wʌn kɔɹnɝ ə ðə bɪldɪŋ bɪsaɪd wɪtʃ ðə tʃɹɑləks hæd stʊd wɑz sɪmpli ɡɔn, fleɪmz lɪkɪŋ əɾ ɛnz ə plæŋks ən ɹæftɝz. ʌv ðə tʃɹɑləks ðəɹ wɑz noʊ saɪn.

Blinking, Rand staggered to his feet, coughing in thick, acrid smoke, ears ringing. He stared in amazement.
