Half the tubes and all of the racks lay on their sides, and one corner of the building beside which the Trollocs had stood was simply gone, flames licking at ends of planks and rafters. Of the Trollocs there was no sign.

θɹu ðə ɹɪŋɪŋ ɪn ɪz ɪɹz, ɹænd hɝd ʃaʊts fɹəm ði ɪluməneɪɾɝz ɪn ðə bɪldɪŋ. hi bɹoʊk ɪndə ə tɑɾɝɪŋ ɹʌn, lʌmbɝɾ ɪndə ði æli. hæfweɪ daʊn ɪɾ i stʌmbəld oʊvɝ sʌmθɪŋ ən ɹilaɪzd ɪt wɑz ɪz kloʊk. hi snætʃt ɪɾ ʌp wɪθaʊt pɔzɪŋ. bɪhaɪn hɪm, ðə kɹaɪz ə ði ɪluməneɪɾɝz fɪl ðə naɪt.

Through the ringing in his ears, Rand heard shouts from the Illuminators in the building. He broke into a tottering run, lumbered into the alley. Halfway down it he stumbled over something and realized it was his cloak. He snatched it up without pausing. Behind him, the cries of the Illuminators filled the night.

lɔɪəl wɑz baʊnsɪŋ ɪmpeɪʃənli ɑn ɪz fit bɪsaɪd ði oʊpən dɔɹ. ən i wɑz əloʊn.

Loial was bouncing impatiently on his feet beside the open door. And he was alone.

"wɛɹ ɪz səlin?" ɹænd dɪmændəd.

"Where is Selene?" Rand demanded.

"ʃi wɛn bæk, ɹænd. aɪ tʃɹaɪd tə ɡɹæb hɝ, ən ʃi slɪpt ɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ə maɪ hænz."

"She went back, Rand. I tried to grab her, and she slipped right out of my hands."

ɹænd tɝn bæk təwɔɹd ðə nɔɪz. θɹu ði ɪnsɛsən saʊn ɪn ɪz ɪɹz, səm ə ðə ʃaʊts wɝ bɛɹli dɪstɪŋɡwɪʃəbəl. ðəɹ wɑz laɪt ðɛɹ, naʊ, fɹəm ðə fleɪmz.

Rand turned back toward the noise. Through the incessant sound in his ears, some of the shouts were barely distinguishable. There was light there, now, from the flames.

"ðə sæn bʌkəts! fɛtʃ ðə sæn bʌkəts kwɪkli!"

"The sand buckets! Fetch the sand buckets quickly!"

"ðɪs ɪz dɪzæstɝ! dɪzæstɝ!"

"This is disaster! Disaster!"

"sʌm ə ðɛm wɛn ðət weɪ!"

"Some of them went that way!"

lɔɪəl ɡɹæbd ɹændz ʃoʊldɝ. "ju kænɑt hɛlp hɝ, ɹænd. nɑt baɪ biɪŋ teɪkən jɝsɛlf. wi mʌst ɡoʊ." sʌmwʌn əpɪɹɾ ət ði ɛn ə ði æli, ə ʃædoʊ aʊtlaɪn baɪ ðə ɡloʊ ʌv fleɪmz bɪhaɪnd, ən pɔɪntəd təwɔɹd ðɛm. "kʌm ɑn, ɹænd!"

Loial grabbed Rand's shoulder. "You cannot help her, Rand. Not by being taken yourself. We must go." Someone appeared at the end of the alley, a shadow outlined by the glow of flames behind, and pointed toward them. "Come on, Rand!"

ɹænd lɛt hɪmsɛlf bi pʊld aʊɾ ə ðə dɔɹ ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs. ðə faɪɝ feɪɾəd bɪhaɪn əm əntɪl ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə ɡloʊ ɪn ðə naɪt, ən ðə laɪts ə ðə fɔɹɡeɪt keɪm kloʊsɝ. ɹænd ɔlmoʊst wɪʃt mɔɹ tʃɹɑləks wəɾ əpɪɹ, sʌmθɪŋ i kəd faɪt. bʌt ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli ðə naɪt bɹiz ɹʌfəlɪŋ ðə ɡɹæs.

Rand let himself be pulled out of the door into the darkness. The fire faded behind them until it was only a glow in the night, and the lights of the Foregate came closer. Rand almost wished more Trollocs would appear, something he could fight. But there was only the night breeze ruffling the grass.

"aɪ tʃɹaɪd tə stɑp hɝ," lɔɪəl sɛd. ðəɹ wɑz ə lɔŋ saɪləns. "wi ɹɪli kʊdn əv dʌn ɛniθɪŋ. ðeɪ wəd dʒʌst əv teɪkən ʌs, tu."

"I tried to stop her," Loial said. There was a long silence. "We really couldn't have done anything. They would just have taken us, too."

ɹænd saɪd. "aɪ noʊ, lɔɪəl. jə dɪd wʌt jə kʊd." hi wɔk bækwɝdz ə fju stɛps, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə ɡloʊ. ɪt sim lɛs; ði ɪluməneɪɾɝz mʌs bi pʊɾɪŋ aʊt ðə fleɪmz. "aɪ hæv tə hɛlp əɹ sʌmhaʊ." haʊ? seɪɾɪn? ðə paʊɝ? hi ʃɪvɝd. "aɪ hæv tə."

Rand sighed. "I know, Loial. You did what you could." He walked backwards a few steps, staring at the glow. It seemed less; the Illuminators must be putting out the flames. "I have to help her somehow." How? Saidin? The Power? He shivered. "I have to."

ðeɪ wɛn θɹu ðə fɔɹɡeɪt baɪ ðə laɪɾəd stʃɹits, ɹæpt ɪn ə saɪləns ðət ʃʌɾ aʊt ðə ɡeɪəɾi ɝaʊn ðɛm.

They went through the Foregate by the lighted streets, wrapped in a silence that shut out the gaiety around them.

wən ðeɪ ɛntɝd ðə dɪfɛndɝ ə ðə dʒɹæɡoʊnwɔl, ði ɪnkipɝ hɛld aʊɾ ɪz tʃɹeɪ wɪð ə sil pɑɹtʃmənt.

When they entered The Defender of the Dragonwall, the innkeeper held out his tray with a sealed parchment.

ɹænd tʊk ɪt, ən stɛɹɾ ət ðə waɪt sil. ə kɹɛsən mun ən stɑɹz. "hu lɛf ðɪs? wɛn?"

Rand took it, and stared at the white seal. A crescent moon and stars. "Who left this? When?"

"æn oʊld wʊmən, maɪ lɔɹd. nɑɾ ə kɔɹɾɝ ʌv ən aʊɝ ɡɔn. ə sɝvənt, ðoʊ ʃi dɪd nɑt seɪ fɹəm wʌt haʊs." kueɪli smaɪld əz ɪf ɪnvaɪɾɪŋ kɑnfəɾənsɪz.

"An old woman, my Lord. Not a quarter of an hour gone. A servant, though she did not say from what House." Cuale smiled as if inviting confidences.

"θæŋk ju," ɹænd sɛd, stɪl stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə sil. ði ɪnkipɝ wɑtʃt əm ɡoʊ əpstɛɹz wɪð ə θɔtfəl lʊk.

"Thank you," Rand said, still staring at the seal. The innkeeper watched them go upstairs with a thoughtful look.

hʊɹɪn tʊk ɪz paɪp aʊɾ ə hɪz maʊθ wən ɹænd ən lɔɪəl ɛntɝd ðə ɹum. hʊɹɪn hæɾ ɪz ʃɔɹt sɔɹɾ ən sɔɹd-bɹeɪkɝ ɑn ðə teɪbəl, waɪpɪŋ əm wɪð ən ɔɪli ɹæɡ. "ju wɝ lɔŋ wɪð ðə ɡlimən, maɪ lɔɹd. ɪz i wɛl?"

Hurin took his pipe out of his mouth when Rand and Loial entered the room. Hurin had his short sword and sword-breaker on the table, wiping them with an oily rag. "You were long with the gleeman, my Lord. Is he well?"

ɹænd ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt. "wʌt? tɑm? jɛs hiz. . . ." hi bɹoʊk oʊpən ðə sil wɪð ɪz θʌm ən ɹɛd.

Rand gave a start. "What? Thom? Yes he's. . . ." He broke open the seal with his thumb and read.

wən aɪ θɪŋk aɪ noʊ wʌt jə ɑɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə du, jə də sʌmθɪŋ ɛls. jə ɑɹ ə deɪnʒɝəs mæn. pɝhæps ɪɾəl nɑt bi lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ wəɹ təɡɛðɝ əɡɛn. θɪŋk ə ðə hɔɹn. θɪŋk ə ðə ɡlɔɹi. ən θɪŋk ə mi, fəɹ jə ɑɹ ɔlweɪz maɪn.

When I think I know what you are going to do, you do something else. You are a dangerous man. Perhaps it will not be long before we are together again. Think of the Horn. Think of the glory. And think of me, for you are always mine.

əɡɛn, ɪt bɔɹ noʊ sɪɡnətʃɝ bʌt ðə floʊɪŋ hæn ɪtsɛlf.

Again, it bore no signature but the flowing hand itself.

"ɑɹ ɔl wɪmən kɹeɪzi?" ɹænd dɪmændəɾ ə ðə silɪŋ. hʊɹɪn ʃɹʌɡd. ɹænd θɹu hɪmsɛlf ɪndə ði ʌðɝ tʃɛɹ, ðə wʌn saɪz fəɹ ən oʊɡiɝ; hɪz fit dæŋɡəld əbʌv ðə flɔɹ, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt kɛɹ. hi stɛɹɾ ət ðə blæŋkət-kʌvɝd tʃɛst ʌndɝ ði ɛdʒ ə lɔɪəlz bɛd. θɪŋk ə ðə ɡlɔɹi. "aɪ wɪʃ ɪŋtʃɹ wəd kʌm."

"Are all women crazy?" Rand demanded of the ceiling. Hurin shrugged. Rand threw himself into the other chair, the one sized for an Ogier; his feet dangled above the floor, but he did not care. He stared at the blanket-covered chest under the edge of Loial's bed. Think of the glory. "I wish Ingtar would come."


tʃæptɝ twɛntieɪt


CHAPTER 28

eɪ nu θɹɛɾ ɪn ðə pæɾɝn


A New Thread in the Pattern

pɛɹɪn wɑtʃt ðə maʊntənz ə kɪnsleɪɝz dæɡɝ ənkʌmftəbli əz i ɹoʊd. ðə weɪ stɪl slæntəɾ ʌpwɝdz, ən lʊkt əz ɪf ɪt wəd klaɪm fɝɛvɝ, ðoʊ hi θɔt ðə kɹɛst ə ðə pæs mʌs nɑt bi tu mʌtʃ fɝðɝ. tə wʌn saɪɾ ə ðə tʃɹeɪl, ðə læn sləpt ʃɑɹpli daʊn tə ə ʃæloʊ maʊntən stʃɹim, dæʃɪŋ ɪtsɛlf tə fɹɔθ oʊvɝ ʃɑɹp ɹɑks; tə ði ʌðɝ saɪd ðə maʊntənz ɹɪɹɾ ɪn ə sɪɹiz ə dʒæɡd klɪfs, laɪk fɹoʊzən stoʊn wɔɾɝfɔlz. ðə tʃɹeɪl ɪtsɛlf ɹæn θɹu filz ə boʊldɝz, səm ðə saɪz ʌv ə mænz hɛd, ən səm əz bɪɡ əz ə kɑɹt. ɪt wəd teɪk noʊ ɡɹeɪt skɪl tə haɪɾ ɪn ðæt.

Perrin watched the mountains of Kinslayer's Dagger uncomfortably as he rode. The way still slanted upwards, and looked as if it would climb forever, though he thought the crest of the pass must not be too much further. To one side of the trail, the land sloped sharply down to a shallow mountain stream, dashing itself to froth over sharp rocks; to the other side the mountains reared in a series of jagged cliffs, like frozen stone waterfalls. The trail itself ran through fields of boulders, some the size of a man's head, and some as big as a cart. It would take no great skill to hide in that.

ðə wʊlvz sɛd ðəɹ wɝ pipəl ɪn ðə maʊntənz. pɛɹɪn wʌndɝɾ ɪf ðeɪ wɝ səm ə feɪnz dɑɹkfɹɛnz. ðə wʊlvz dɪd nɑt noʊ, əɹ kɛɹ. ðeɪ oʊnli nu ðə twɪstəd wʌnz wɝ sʌmwɛɹ əhɛd. stɪl fɑɹ əhɛd, ðoʊ ɪŋtʃɹ hæd pɹɛs ðə kɑləm hɑɹd. pɛɹɪn noʊɾəst ðəɾ ənoʊ wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ ðə maʊntənz ɝaʊn əm mʌtʃ ðə weɪ hi hɪmsɛlf wɑz.

The wolves said there were people in the mountains. Perrin wondered if they were some of Fain's Darkfriends. The wolves did not know, or care. They only knew the Twisted Ones were somewhere ahead. Still far ahead, though Ingtar had pressed the column hard. Perrin noticed that Uno was watching the mountains around them much the way he himself was.

mæt, hɪz baʊ slʌŋ əkɹɔs ɪz bæk, ɹoʊd wɪð simɪŋ ʌnkənsɝn, dʒʌɡəlɪŋ θɹi kʌlɝd bɔlz, jɛɾ i lʊk pəlɝ ðən i hæd. vɛɹɪn ɪɡzæmən ɪm tu ən θɹi taɪmz ə deɪ naʊ, fɹaʊnɪŋ, ən pɛɹɪn wɑz ʃʊɹ ʃi hæɾ ivən tʃɹaɪd hilɪŋ ət list wʌns, bʌɾ ɪt meɪd noʊ dɪfɝəns pɛɹɪn kəd si. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ʃi sim tə bi mɔɹ əbzɔɹbd ɪn sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt wɪtʃ ʃi dɪd nɑt spik.

Mat, his bow slung across his back, rode with seeming unconcern, juggling three colored balls, yet he looked paler than he had. Verin examined him two and three times a day now, frowning, and Perrin was sure she had even tried Healing at least once, but it made no difference Perrin could see. In any case, she seemed to be more absorbed in something about which she did not speak.

ɹænd, pɛɹɪn θɔt, lʊkɪŋ ət ði ɛɛs sədaɪz bæk. ʃi ɔlweɪz ɹoʊɾ ət ðə hɛɾ ə ðə kɑləm wɪð ɪŋtʃɹ, ən ʃi ɔlweɪz wɑntəɾ əm tə muv ivən fæstɝ ðən ðə ʃaɪnɝən lɔɹd wəɾ əlaʊ. sʌmhaʊ, ʃi noʊz əbaʊt ɹænd. ɪmədʒəz fɹəm ðə wʊlvz flɪkɝɾ ɪn ɪz hɛd - stoʊn fɑɹmhaʊsəz ən tɛɹəs vɪlədʒəz, ɔl bɪɑn ðə maʊntən piks; ðə wʊlvz sɔ ðɛm noʊ dɪfɹənli ðən ðeɪ sɔ hɪlz əɹ mɛdoʊz, ɪksɛpt wɪð ə filɪŋ ðət ðeɪ wɝ spɔɪld lænd. fəɹ ə moʊmən i faʊn hɪmsɛlf ʃɛɹɪŋ ðət ɹəɡɹɛt, ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ pleɪsəz ðə tu-lɛɡz hæd lɔŋ sɪns əbændənd, ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ðə swɪft ɹʌʃ θɹu ðə tʃɹiz, ən ðə hæm-stʃɹɪŋɪŋ snæp ə hɪz dʒɔz əz ðə dɪɹ tʃɹaɪd tə fli, ænd. . . . wɪð ən ɛfɝɾ i pʊʃt ðə wʊlvz aʊɾ ə hɪz hɛd. ðiz ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑɹ gɑnə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ɔl ʌv ʌs.

Rand, Perrin thought, looking at the Aes Sedai's back. She always rode at the head of the column with Ingtar, and she always wanted them to move even faster than the Shienaran lord would allow. Somehow, she knows about Rand. Images from the wolves flickered in his head - stone farmhouses and terraced villages, all beyond the mountain peaks; the wolves saw them no differently than they saw hills or meadows, except with a feeling that they were spoiled land. For a moment he found himself sharing that regret, remembering places the two-legs had long since abandoned, remembering the swift rush through the trees, and the ham-stringing snap of his jaws as the deer tried to flee, and. . . . With an effort he pushed the wolves out of his head. These Aes Sedai are going to destroy all of us.

ɪŋtʃɹ lɛɾ ɪz hɔɹs fɔl bæk bɪsaɪd pɛɹɪnz. səmtaɪmz, tə pɛɹɪnz aɪz, ðə kɹɛsən kɹɛst ɑn ðə ʃaɪnɝənz hɛlmət lʊk laɪk ə tʃɹɑlɑks hɔɹnz. ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd sɔfli, "tɛl mi əɡɛn wʌt ðə wʊlvz sɛd."

Ingtar let his horse fall back beside Perrin's. Sometimes, to Perrin's eyes, the crescent crest on the Shienaran's helmet looked like a Trolloc's horns. Ingtar said softly, "Tell me again what the wolves said."

"aɪv toʊl jə tɛn taɪmz," pɛɹɪn mʌɾɝd.

"I've told you ten times," Perrin muttered.

"tɛl mi əɡɛn! ɛniθɪŋ aɪ meɪ hæv mɪst, ɛniθɪŋ ðət wɪl hɛlp mi faɪn ðə hɔɹn. . . ." ɪŋtʃɹ dʒɹu ə bɹɛθ ən lɛɾ ɪɾ aʊt sloʊli. "aɪ mʌs faɪn ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ, pɛɹɪn. tɛl mi əɡɛn."

"Tell me again! Anything I may have missed, anything that will help me find the Horn. . . ." Ingtar drew a breath and let it out slowly. "I must find the Horn of Valere, Perrin. Tell me again."

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid fəɹ pɛɹɪn tə ɔɹɾɝ ɪɾ ɪn ɪz maɪnd, nɑɾ æftɝ soʊ mɛni ɹɛpətɪʃənz. hi dʒɹoʊn ɪɾ aʊt. "sʌmwʌn - əɹ sʌmθɪŋ - ətæk ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz ɪn ðə naɪɾ ən kɪl ðoʊz tʃɹɑləks wi faʊnd." hɪz stʌmək noʊ lɔŋɡɝ lɝtʃt ət ðæt. ɹeɪvənz ən vʌltʃɝz wɝ mɛsi fiɾɝz. "ðə wʊlvz kɔl ɪm - əɹ ɪt - ʃæɾoʊkɪlɝ; aɪ θɪŋk ɪt wɑz ə mæn, bʌt ðeɪ wʊdnt ɡoʊ kloʊs ɪnʌf tə si klɪɹli. ðeɪ ɑɹ nɑɾ əfɹeɪɾ ə ðɪs ʃæɾoʊkɪlɝ; ɑ ɪz mɔɹ laɪk ɪt. ðeɪ seɪ ðə tʃɹɑləks naʊ fɑloʊ ʃæɾoʊkɪlɝ. ən ðeɪ seɪ feɪn ɪz wɪð ðɛm" - ivən æftɝ soʊ lɔŋ ðə ɹɪmɛmbɝd smɛl ə feɪn, ðə fil ə ðə mæn, meɪɾ ɪz maʊθ twɪst - "soʊ ðə ɹɛst ə ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz mʌs bi, tu."

There was no need for Perrin to order it in his mind, not after so many repetitions. He droned it out. "Someone - or something - attacked the Darkfriends in the night and killed those Trollocs we found." His stomach no longer lurched at that. Ravens and vultures were messy feeders. "The wolves call him - or it - Shadowkiller; I think it was a man, but they wouldn't go close enough to see clearly. They are not afraid of this Shadowkiller; awe is more like it. They say the Trollocs now follow Shadowkiller. And they say Fain is with them" - even after so long the remembered smell of Fain, the feel of the man, made his mouth twist - "so the rest of the Darkfriends must be, too."

"ʃæɾoʊkɪlɝ," ɪŋtʃɹ mɝmɝd. "sʌmθɪŋ ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn, laɪk ə mɹdʒɹɑl? aɪ hæv sin θɪŋz ɪn ðə blaɪt ðət maɪt bi kɔld ʃæɾoʊkɪlɝz, bʌt. . . . dɪd ðeɪ si nʌθɪŋ ɛls?"

"Shadowkiller," Ingtar murmured. "Something of the Dark One, like a Myrddraal? I have seen things in the Blight that might be called Shadowkillers, but. . . . Did they see nothing else?"

"ðeɪ wəd nɑt kʌm kloʊs tə hɪm. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə feɪd. aɪv toʊl ju, ðəl kɪl ə feɪd kwɪkɝ ðən ðəl ə tʃɹɑlɑk, ivən ɪf ðeɪ luz hæf ðə pæk. ɪŋtʃɹ, ðə wʊlvz u sɔ ɪt pæs ðɪs tə ʌðɝz, ðən stɪl ʌðɝz, bɪfɔɹ ɪt ɹitʃt mi. aɪ kən oʊnli tɛl jə wʌt ðeɪ pæst ɑn, ən æftɝ soʊ mɛni tɛlɪŋz. . . ." hi lɛt ðə wɝdz daɪ əz ənoʊ dʒɔɪn ðɛm.

"They would not come close to him. It was not a Fade. I've told you, they will kill a Fade quicker than they will a Trolloc, even if they lose half the pack. Ingtar, the wolves who saw it passed this to others, then still others, before it reached me. I can only tell you what they passed on, and after so many tellings. . . ." He let the words die as Uno joined them.

"ilmən ɪn ðə ɹɑks," ðə wʌn-aɪd mæn sɛd kwaɪətli.

"Aielman in the rocks," the one-eyed man said quietly.

"ðɪs fɑɹ fɹəm ðə weɪst?" ɪŋtʃɹ sɛɾ ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli. ənoʊ sʌmhaʊ mænədʒ tə lʊk əfɛndəd wɪθaʊt tʃeɪnʒɪŋ ɪz ɪkspɹɛʃən, ən ɪŋtʃɹ æɾəd, "noʊ, aɪ doʊn daʊt ju. aɪm dʒʌst sɝpɹaɪzd."

"This far from the Waste?" Ingtar said incredulously. Uno somehow managed to look offended without changing his expression, and Ingtar added, "No, I don't doubt you. I am just surprised."

"hi fleɪmɪŋ wɑntəd mi tə si hɪm, əɹ aɪ laɪkli wʊdn hæv." ənoʊ saʊndəd dɪsɡʌstəɾ əɾ ædmɪɾɪŋ ɪt. "æn ɪz blʌɾi feɪs wɑzn veɪld, soʊ hiz nɑɾ aʊt fəɹ kɪlɪŋ. bʌt wən jə si wʌn blʌɾi il, ðɛɹz ɔlweɪz mɔɹ jə doʊnt." sʌɾənli hɪz aɪ waɪɾənd. "bɝn mi ɪf ɪt dʌzn lʊk laɪk i blʌɾi wɑns mɔɹ ðən tə bi sin." hi pɔɪntəd: ə mæn hæd stɛpt ɪndə ðə weɪ əhɛɾ ə ðɛm.

"He flaming wanted me to see him, or I likely wouldn't have." Uno sounded disgusted at admitting it. "And his bloody face wasn't veiled, so he's not out for killing. But when you see one bloody Aiel, there's always more you don't." Suddenly his eye widened. "Burn me if it doesn't look like he bloody wants more than to be seen." He pointed: a man had stepped into the way ahead of them.

ɪnstənli mæsiməz læns dʒɹɑp tə ə kaʊtʃ, ən i dʌɡ hɪz hilz ɪndə hɪz hɔɹs, lipɪŋ tə ə dɛd ɡæləp ɪn θɹi stʃɹaɪdz. hi wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn; fɔɹ stil pɔɪns hɝɾəld təwɔɹd ðə mæn ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd.

Instantly Masema's lance dropped to a couch, and he dug his heels into his horse, leaping to a dead gallop in three strides. He was not the only one; four steel points hurtled toward the man on the ground.

"hoʊld!" ɪŋtʃɹ ʃaʊɾəd. "hoʊld, aɪ sɛd! əl əv ði ɪɹz ʌv ɛni mæn u dʌzn stɑp wɛɹ i stænz!"

"Hold!" Ingtar shouted. "Hold, I said! I'll have the ears of any man who doesn't stop where he stands!"

mæsimə pʊld ɪn ɪz hɔɹs vɪʃəsli, sɔɪŋ ðə ɹeɪnz. ði ʌðɝz ɔlsoʊ stɑpt, ɪn ə klaʊɾ ə dʌs nɑt tɛn peɪsɪz fɹəm ðə mæn, ðɛɹ lænsɪz stɪl hɛl stɛɾi ɑn ðə mænz tʃɛst. hi ɹeɪzd ə hæn tə weɪv əweɪ ðə dʌst əz ɪt dʒɹɪftəd təwɔɹd hɪm; ɪt wɑz ðə fɝs muv i hæd meɪd.

Masema pulled in his horse viciously, sawing the reins. The others also stopped, in a cloud of dust not ten paces from the man, their lances still held steady on the man's chest. He raised a hand to wave away the dust as it drifted toward him; it was the first move he had made.

hi wɑz ə tɔl mæn, wɪð skɪn dɑɹk fɹəm ðə sʌn ən ɹɛd hɛɹ kʌt ʃɔɹɾ ɪksɛp fəɹ ə teɪl ɪn ðə bæk ðət hʌŋ tə hɪz ʃoʊldɝz. fɹəm ɪz sɑft, leɪs ni-haɪ buts tə ðə klɔθ ɹæp lusli ɝaʊn ɪz nɛk, hɪz kloʊðz wɝ ɔl ɪn ʃeɪdz ə bɹaʊn ən ɡɹeɪ ðət wəd blɛn ɪndə ɹɑk əɹ ɝθ. ði ɛn ʌv ə ʃɔɹt hɔɹn baʊ pikt oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, ən ə kwɪvɝ bɹɪsəld wɪð æɹoʊz əɾ ɪz bɛlt ət wʌn saɪd. ə lɔŋ naɪf hʌŋ ət ði ʌðɝ. ɪn ɪz lɛf hæn i ɡɹɪpt ə ɹaʊn haɪd bʌkəlɝ ən θɹi ʃɔɹt spɪɹz, noʊ mɔɹ ðən hæf əz lɔŋ əz i wɑz tɔl, wɪð pɔɪns fʊli əz lɔŋ əz ðoʊz ə ðə ʃaɪnɝən lænsɪz.

He was a tall man, with skin dark from the sun and red hair cut short except for a tail in the back that hung to his shoulders. From his soft, laced knee-high boots to the cloth wrapped loosely around his neck, his clothes were all in shades of brown and gray that would blend into rock or earth. The end of a short horn bow peeked over his shoulder, and a quiver bristled with arrows at his belt at one side. A long knife hung at the other. In his left hand he gripped a round hide buckler and three short spears, no more than half as long as he was tall, with points fully as long as those of the Shienaran lances.

"aɪ hæv noʊ paɪpɝz tə pleɪ ðə tun," ðə mæn ənaʊnst wɪð ə smaɪl, "bʌɾ ɪf jə wɪʃ ðə dæns. . . ." hi dɪd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ ɪz stæns, bʌt pɛɹɪn kɑɾ ə sʌɾən ɛɹ ə ɹɛɾinəs. "maɪ neɪm ɪz jɝaɪn, ʌv ðə tu spaɪɹz sɛpt ə ðə ɹn il. aɪm ə ɹɛd ʃild. ɹɪmɛmbɝ mi."

"I have no pipers to play the tune," the man announced with a smile, "but if you wish the dance. . . ." He did not change his stance, but Perrin caught a sudden air of readiness. "My name is Urien, of the Two Spires sept of the Reyn Aiel. I am a Red Shield. Remember me."

ɪŋtʃɹ dɪsmaʊntɪɾ ən wɔk fɔɹwɝd, ɹimuvɪŋ ɪz hɛlmət. pɛɹɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd oʊnli ə moʊmən bɪfɔɹ klaɪmɪŋ daʊn tə dʒɔɪn hɪm. hi kəd nɑt mɪs ðə tʃæns tə si ən il kloʊs ʌp. æktɪŋ laɪk ə blæk-veɪld il. ɪn stɔɹi æftɝ stɔɹi il wɝ əz dɛdli ən deɪnʒɝəs əz tʃɹɑləks - səm ivən sɛd ðeɪ wɝ ɔl dɑɹkfɹɛnz - bʌt jɝaɪnz smaɪl sʌmhaʊ dɪd nɑt lʊk deɪnʒɝəs dɪspaɪt ðə fæk ðəɾ i sim pɔɪz tə lip. hɪz aɪz wɝ blu.

Ingtar dismounted and walked forward, removing his helmet. Perrin hesitated only a moment before climbing down to join him. He could not miss the chance to see an Aiel close up. Acting like a black-veiled Aiel. In story after story Aiel were as deadly and dangerous as Trollocs - some even said they were all Darkfriends - but Urien's smile somehow did not look dangerous despite the fact that he seemed poised to leap. His eyes were blue.

"hi lʊks laɪk ɹænd." pɛɹɪn lʊkt ɝaʊn tə si ðət mæt hæd dʒɔɪn ðɛm, tu. "meɪbi ɪŋtʃɹz ɹaɪt," mæt æɾəd kwaɪətli. "meɪbi ɹænd ɪz ən il."

"He looks like Rand." Perrin looked around to see that Mat had joined them, too. "Maybe Ingtar's right," Mat added quietly. "Maybe Rand is an Aiel."

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd. "bʌɾ ɪt dʌzn tʃeɪnʒ ɛniθɪŋ."

Perrin nodded. "But it doesn't change anything."

"noʊ, ɪt dʌznt." mæt saʊndəɾ əz ɪf i wɝ tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt sʌmθɪŋ bɪsaɪd wʌt pɛɹɪn mɛnt.

"No, it doesn't." Mat sounded as if he were talking about something beside what Perrin meant.

"wi ɑɹ boʊθ fɑɹ fɹəm əɹ hoʊmz," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd tə ði il, "ænd wi, ət list, hæv kʌm fəɹ ʌðɝ θɪŋz ðən faɪɾɪŋ." pɛɹɪn ɹɪvaɪzd ɪz əpɪnjən ə jɝaɪnz smaɪl; ðə mæn æktʃəli  lʊk dɪsəpɔɪntɪd.

"We are both far from our homes," Ingtar said to the Aiel, "and we, at least, have come for other things than fighting." Perrin revised his opinion of Urien's smile; the man actually looked disappointed.

"æz jə wɪʃ ɪt, ʃaɪnɝən." jɝaɪn tɝn tə vɛɹɪn, dʒʌst ɡɛɾɪŋ daʊn ɔf əɹ hɔɹs, ən meɪɾ ən ɑd baʊ, dɪɡɪŋ ðə pɔɪns ə hɪz spɪɹz ɪndə ðə ɡɹaʊn ən ɪkstɛndɪŋ ɪz ɹaɪt hænd, pɑm ʌp. hɪz vɔɪs bɪkeɪm ɹɪspɛkfəl. "waɪz wʌn, maɪ wɔɾɝ ɪz jʊɹz."

"As you wish it, Shienaran." Urien turned to Verin, just getting down off her horse, and made an odd bow, digging the points of his spears into the ground and extending his right hand, palm up. His voice became respectful. "Wise One, my water is yours."

vɛɹɪn hændəɾ əɹ ɹeɪnz tə wʌn ə ðə soʊlʒɝz. ʃi stʌɾid ði il əz ʃi keɪm kloʊsɝ. "waɪ dʒju kɔl mi ðæt? dʒju teɪk mi fəɹ ən il?"

Verin handed her reins to one of the soldiers. She studied the Aiel as she came closer. "Why do you call me that? Do you take me for an Aiel?"

"noʊ, waɪz wʌn. bʌt juv ðə lʊk ə ðoʊz u hæv meɪd ðə dʒɝni tə ɹɪɾiən ən sɝvaɪvd. ðə jɪɹz də nɑt tʌtʃ ðə waɪz wʌnz ɪn ðə seɪm weɪ əz ʌðɝ wɪmən, əɹ əz ðeɪ tʌtʃ mɛn."

"No, Wise One. But you have the look of those who have made the journey to Rhuidean and survived. The years do not touch the Wise Ones in the same way as other women, or as they touch men."

ən ɪksaɪɾəd lʊk əpɪɹɾ ɑn ði ɛɛs sədaɪz feɪs, bʌɾ ɪŋtʃɹ spoʊk ɪmpeɪʃənli. "wi ɑɹ fɑloʊɪŋ dɑɹkfɹɛnz ən tʃɹɑləks, jɝaɪn. hæv jə sin ɛni saɪn ə ðɛm?"

An excited look appeared on the Aes Sedai's face, but Ingtar spoke impatiently. "We are following Darkfriends and Trollocs, Urien. Have you seen any sign of them?"

"tʃɹɑləks? hɪɹ?" jɝaɪnz aɪz bɹaɪɾənd. "ɪɾ ɪz wʌn ə ðə saɪnz ðə pɹɑfəsiz spik ʌv. wən ðə tʃɹɑləks kʌm aʊɾ ə ðə blaɪɾ əɡɛn, wɪl liv ðə θɹi-foʊld læn ən teɪk bæk əɹ pleɪsəz ʌv oʊld." ðəɹ wɑz mʌɾɝɪŋ fɹəm ðə maʊntəd ʃaɪnɝənz. jɝaɪn aɪɾ əm wɪð ə pɹaɪd ðət meɪɾ ɪm sim tə bi lʊkɪŋ daʊn fɹəm ə haɪt.

"Trollocs? Here?" Urien's eyes brightened. "It is one of the signs the prophecies speak of. When the Trollocs come out of the Blight again, we will leave the Three-fold Land and take back our places of old." There was muttering from the mounted Shienarans. Urien eyed them with a pride that made him seem to be looking down from a height.

"ðə θɹi-foʊld lænd?" mæt sɛd.

"The Three-fold Land?" Mat said.

pɛɹɪn θɔɾ i lʊk stɪl pəlɝ; nɑt sɪk, ɪɡzækli, bʌɾ əz ɪf i hæd bɪn aʊɾ ə ðə sʌn tu lɔŋ.

Perrin thought he looked still paler; not sick, exactly, but as if he had been out of the sun too long.

"ju kɔl ɪt ðə weɪst," jɝaɪn sɛd. "tə əs ɪts ðə θɹi-foʊld lænd. ə ʃeɪpɪŋ stoʊn, tə meɪk ʌs; ə tɛstɪŋ ɡɹaʊnd, tə pɹuv əɹ wɝθ; ən ə pʌnɪʃmən fəɹ ðə sɪn."

"You call it the Waste," Urien said. "To us it is the Three-fold Land. A shaping stone, to make us; a testing ground, to prove our worth; and a punishment for the sin."

"wʌt sɪn?" mæt æskt. pɛɹɪn kɑɾ ɪz bɹɛθ, weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ðə spɪɹz ɪn jɝaɪnz hæn tə flæʃ.

"What sin?" Mat asked. Perrin caught his breath, waiting for the spears in Urien's hand to flash.

ði il ʃɹʌɡd. "soʊ lɔŋ əɡoʊ ɪt wɑz, ðət nʌn ɹɪmɛmbɝ. ɪksɛp ðə waɪz wʌnz ən ðə klæn tʃifs, ən ðəl nɑt spik ʌv ɪt. ɪt mʌst əv bɪn ə vɛɹi ɡɹeɪt sɪn ɪf ðeɪ kænɑt bɹɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz tə tɛl ʌs, bʌt ðə kɹieɪɾɝ pʌnɪʃəz əs wɛl."

The Aiel shrugged. "So long ago it was, that none remember. Except the Wise Ones and the clan chiefs, and they will not speak of it. It must have been a very great sin if they cannot bring themselves to tell us, but the Creator punishes us well."

"tʃɹɑləks," ɪŋtʃɹ pɝsɪstəd. "hæv jə sin tʃɹɑləks?"

"Trollocs," Ingtar persisted. "Have you seen Trollocs?"

jɝaɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "aɪ wʊɾə kɪld əm ɪf aɪ hæd, bʌɾ aɪ hæv sin nʌθɪŋ bʌt ðə ɹɑks ən ðə skaɪ."

Urien shook his head. "I would have killed them if I had, but I have seen nothing but the rocks and the sky."

ɪŋtʃɹ ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, luzɪŋ ɪntʃɹəst, bʌt vɛɹɪn spoʊk, ʃɑɹp kɑnsəntʃɹeɪʃən ɪn əɹ vɔɪs. "ðɪs ɹɪɾiən. wʌɾ ɪz ɪt? wɛɹ ɪz ɪt? haʊ ɑɹ ðə ɡɝlz tʃoʊzən tə ɡoʊ?"

Ingtar shook his head, losing interest, but Verin spoke, sharp concentration in her voice. "This Rhuidean. What is it? Where is it? How are the girls chosen to go?"

jɝaɪnz feɪs wɛn flæt, hɪz aɪz hʊɾɪd. "aɪ kænɑt spik ʌv ɪt, waɪz wʌn."

Urien's face went flat, his eyes hooded. "I cannot speak of it, Wise One."

ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɪmsɛlf pɛɹɪnz hænd ɡɹɪpt ɪz æks. ðəɹ wɑz ðəɾ ɪn jɝaɪnz vɔɪs. ɪŋtʃɹ hæɾ ɔlsoʊ sɛt hɪmsɛlf, ɹɛɾi tə ɹitʃ fəɹ ɪz sɔɹd, ən ðəɹ wɑz ə stɝ əmʌŋ ðə maʊntəd mɛn. bʌt vɛɹɪn stɛpt ʌp tə ði il, əntɪl ʃi wɑz ɔlmoʊs tʌtʃɪŋ ɪz tʃɛst, ən lʊkt ʌp ɪndə hɪz feɪs.

In spite of himself Perrin's hand gripped his axe. There was that in Urien's voice. Ingtar had also set himself, ready to reach for his sword, and there was a stir among the mounted men. But Verin stepped up to the Aiel, until she was almost touching his chest, and looked up into his face.

"aɪ æm nɑɾ ə waɪz wʌn əz jə noʊ ðɛm, jɝaɪn," ʃi sɛɾ ɪnsɪstənli. "aɪ æm ɛɛs sədaɪ. tɛl mi wʌt jə kən seɪ ʌv ɹɪɾiən."

"I am not a Wise One as you know them, Urien," she said insistently. "I am Aes Sedai. Tell me what you can say of Rhuidean."

ðə mæn u hæd bɪn ɹɛɾi tə feɪs twɛnti mɛn naʊ lʊkt əz ɪf i wɪʃt fəɹ ən ɪskeɪp fɹəm ðɪs wʌn plʌmp wʊmən wɪð ɡɹeɪɪŋ hɛɹ. "aɪ . . . kən tɛl jə oʊnli wʌɾ ɪz noʊn tə ɔl. ɹɪɾiən laɪz ɪn ðə lænz ə ðə dʒɛn il, ðə θɝtinθ klæn. aɪ kænɑt spik ə ðɛm ɪksɛp tə neɪm ðɛm. nʌn meɪ ɡoʊ ðəɹ seɪv wɪmən u wɪʃ tə bɪkʌm waɪz wʌnz, əɹ mɛn u wɪʃ tə bi klæn tʃifs. pɝhæps ðə dʒɛn il tʃuz əmʌŋ ðɛm; aɪ də nɑt noʊ. mɛni ɡoʊ; fju ɹɪtɝn, ən ðoʊz ɑɹ mɑɹkt əz wʌt ðeɪ ɑɹ - waɪz wʌnz, əɹ klæn tʃifs. noʊ mɔɹ kən aɪ seɪ, ɛɛs sədaɪ. noʊ mɔɹ."

The man who had been ready to face twenty men now looked as if he wished for an escape from this one plump woman with graying hair. "I . . . can tell you only what is known to all. Rhuidean lies in the lands of the Jenn Aiel, the thirteenth clan. I cannot speak of them except to name them. None may go there save women who wish to become Wise Ones, or men who wish to be clan chiefs. Perhaps the Jenn Aiel choose among them; I do not know. Many go; few return, and those are marked as what they are - Wise Ones, or clan chiefs. No more can I say, Aes Sedai. No more."

vɛɹɪn kəntɪnjud tə lʊk ʌp ət hɪm, pɝsɪŋ əɹ lɪps.

Verin continued to look up at him, pursing her lips.

jɝaɪn lʊkt ət ðə skaɪ əz ðoʊ hi wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɪt. "wɪl jə sleɪ mi naʊ, ɛɛs sədaɪ?"

Urien looked at the sky as though he was trying to remember it. "Will you slay me now, Aes Sedai?"

ʃi blɪŋkt. "wʌt?"

She blinked. "What?"

"wɪl jə sleɪ mi naʊ? wʌn ə ði oʊl pɹɑfəsiz sɛz ðəɾ ɪf ɛvɝ wi feɪl ði ɛɛs sədaɪ əɡɛn, ðəl sleɪ ʌs. aɪ noʊ jəɹ paʊɝ ɪz ɡɹeɪɾɝ ðən ðəɾ ə ðə waɪz wʌnz." ði il læf sʌɾənli, mɝθləsli. ðəɹ wɑz ə waɪld laɪɾ ɪn ɪz aɪz. "bɹɪŋ jəɹ laɪtnɪŋz, ɛɛs sədaɪ. əl dæns wɪð ðɛm."

"Will you slay me now? One of the old prophecies says that if ever we fail the Aes Sedai again, they will slay us. I know your power is greater than that of the Wise Ones." The Aiel laughed suddenly, mirthlessly. There was a wild light in his eyes. "Bring your lightnings, Aes Sedai. I will dance with them."

ði il θɔɾ i wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə daɪ, ən i wɑz nɑɾ əfɹeɪd. pɛɹɪn ɹilaɪzd ɪz maʊθ wɑz oʊpən ən kloʊzd ɪt wɪð ə snæp.

The Aiel thought he was going to die, and he was not afraid. Perrin realized his mouth was open and closed it with a snap.

"wʌt wəɾ aɪ nɑt ɡɪv," vɛɹɪn mɝmɝd, ɡeɪzɪŋ ʌp ət jɝaɪn, "tə hæv jə ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ. əɹ dʒʌst wɪlɪŋ tə tɔk. oʊ, bi stɪl, mæn. aɪ woʊn hɑɹm ju. ənlɛs jə min tə hɑɹm mi, wɪð jəɹ tɔk ə dænsɪŋ."

"What would I not give," Verin murmured, gazing up at Urien, "to have you in the White Tower. Or just willing to talk. Oh, be still, man. I won't harm you. Unless you mean to harm me, with your talk of dancing."

jɝaɪn simd əstaʊndɪd. hi lʊkt ət ðə ʃaɪnɝənz, sɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz ɔl ɝaʊnd, əz ɪf i səspɛktəd səm tʃɹɪk. "ju ɑɹ nɑɾ ə meɪɾən ə ðə spɪɹ," hi sɛd sloʊli. "haʊ kəɾ aɪ stʃɹaɪk əɾ ə wʊmən u hæz nɑt wɛɾəd ðə spɪɹ? ɪts fɔɹbɪɾən ɪksɛp tə seɪv laɪf, ən ðən aɪ wəd teɪk wunz tə əvɔɪɾ ɪt."

Urien seemed astounded. He looked at the Shienarans, sitting their horses all around, as if he suspected some trick. "You are not a Maiden of the Spear," he said slowly. "How could I strike at a woman who has not wedded the spear? It is forbidden except to save life, and then I would take wounds to avoid it."

"waɪ ɑɹ jə hɪɹ, soʊ fɑɹ fɹəm jəɹ oʊn lænz?" ʃi æskt. "waɪ dɪd jə kʌm tə ʌs? jə cʊɾə ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ðə ɹɑks, ən wi wəd nɛvɝ əv noʊn jə wɝ ðɛɹ." ði il hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ən ʃi æɾəd, "tɛl oʊnli wʌt jə ɑɹ wɪlɪŋ tə seɪ. aɪ də nɑt noʊ wʌt jəɹ waɪz wʌnz du, bʌɾ əl nɑt hɑɹm ju, əɹ tʃɹaɪ tə fɔɹs ju."

"Why are you here, so far from your own lands?" she asked. "Why did you come to us? You could have remained in the rocks, and we would never have known you were there." The Aiel hesitated, and she added, "Tell only what you are willing to say. I do not know what your Wise Ones do, but I'll not harm you, or try to force you."

"soʊ ðə waɪz wʌnz seɪ," jɝaɪn sɛd dʒɹaɪli, "jɛɾ ivən ə klæn tʃif mʌst əv ə stʃɹɔŋ bɛli tə əvɔɪd duɪŋ əz ðeɪ wɑnt." hi sim tə bi pɪkɪŋ ɪz wɝdz kɛɹfəli. "aɪ sɝtʃ fəɹ . . . sʌmwʌn. ə mæn." hɪz aɪ ɹæn əkɹɔs pɛɹɪn, mæt, ðə ʃaɪnɝənz, dɪsmɪsɪŋ əm ɔl. "hi hu kʌmz wɪð ðə dɔn. ɪts sɛd ðəɹ wɪl bi ɡɹeɪt saɪnz ən pɔɹtɛns ə hɪz kʌmɪŋ. aɪ sɔ ðət jə wɝ fɹəm ʃaɪnɝ baɪ jəɹ ɛskɔɹts ɑɹmɝ, ən jə hæd ðə lʊk ʌv ə waɪz wʌn, soʊ aɪ θɔt jə maɪɾ əv wɝɾ ʌv ɡɹeɪɾ ɪvɛns, ði ɪvɛns ðət maɪt hɛɹəl hɪm."

"So the Wise Ones say," Urien said dryly, "yet even a clan chief must have a strong belly to avoid doing as they want." He seemed to be picking his words carefully. "I search for . . . someone. A man." His eye ran across Perrin, Mat, the Shienarans, dismissing them all. "He Who Comes With the Dawn. It is said there will be great signs and portents of his coming. I saw that you were from Shienar by your escort's armor, and you had the look of a Wise One, so I thought you might have word of great events, the events that might herald him."

"ə mæn?" vɛɹɪnz vɔɪs wɑz sɑft, bʌɾ əɹ aɪz wɝ əz ʃɑɹp əz dæɡɝz. "wʌɾ ɑɹ ðiz saɪnz?"

"A man?" Verin's voice was soft, but her eyes were as sharp as daggers. "What are these signs?"

jɝaɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ɪɾ ɪz sɛd wɪl noʊ ðɛm wən wi hɪɹ ə ðɛm, əz wɪl noʊ hɪm wən wi si hɪm, fəɹ hɪl bi mɑɹkt. hɪl kʌm fɹəm ðə wɛst, bɪɑn ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝld, bʌt bi ʌv əɹ blʌd. hɪl ɡoʊ tə ɹɪɾiən, ən lɛɾ əs aʊɾ ə ðə θɹi-foʊld lænd." hi tʊk ə spɪɹ ɪn ɪz ɹaɪt hænd. lɛðɝ ən mɛɾəl kɹikt əz soʊlʒɝz ɹitʃt fəɹ ðɛɹ sɔɹdz, ən pɛɹɪn ɹilaɪzd i hæd teɪkən hoʊld ə hɪz æks əɡɛn, bʌt vɛɹɪn weɪvd əm ɔl tə stɪlnəs wɪð ən ɪɹəteɪɾəd lʊk. ɪn ðə dɝt jɝaɪn skɹeɪpt ə sɝkəl wɪð ɪz spɪɹpɔɪnt, ðən dʒɹu əkɹɔs ɪɾ ə sɪnwəs laɪn. "ɪɾ ɪz sɛd ðəɾ ʌndɝ ðɪs saɪn, hɪl kɑŋkɝ."

Urien shook his head. "It is said we will know them when we hear of them, as we will know him when we see him, for he will be marked. He will come from the west, beyond the Spine of the World, but be of our blood. He will go to Rhuidean, and lead us out of the Three-fold Land." He took a spear in his right hand. Leather and metal creaked as soldiers reached for their swords, and Perrin realized he had taken hold of his axe again, but Verin waved them all to stillness with an irritated look. In the dirt Urien scraped a circle with his spearpoint, then drew across it a sinuous line. "It is said that under this sign, he will conquer."

ɪŋtʃɹ fɹaʊn ət ðə sɪmbəl, noʊ ɹɛkəɡnɪʃən ɑn ɪz feɪs, bʌt mæt mʌɾɝd sʌmθɪŋ kɔɹsli ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ, ən pɛɹɪn fɛlt ɪz maʊθ ɡoʊ dʒɹaɪ. ði eɪntʃən sɪmbəl ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Ingtar frowned at the symbol, no recognition on his face, but Mat muttered something coarsely under his breath, and Perrin felt his mouth go dry. The ancient symbol of the Aes Sedai.

vɛɹɪn skɹeɪp ðə mɑɹkɪŋ əweɪ wɪð əɹ fʊt. "aɪ kænɑt tɛl jə wɛɹ i ɪz, jɝaɪn," ʃi sɛd, "æn aɪ hæv hɝɾ ə noʊ saɪnz əɹ pɔɹtɛns tə ɡaɪd jə tə hɪm."

Verin scraped the marking away with her foot. "I cannot tell you where he is, Urien," she said, "and I have heard of no signs or portents to guide you to him."

"ðɛn əl kəntɪnju maɪ sɝtʃ." ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə kwɛstʃən, jɛt jɝaɪn weɪɾəd əntɪl ʃi nɑɾəd bɪfɔɹ i aɪd ðə ʃaɪnɝənz pɹaʊdli, tʃælənʒɪŋli, ðən tɝn ɪz bæk ɑn ðɛm. hi wɔkt əweɪ smuðli, ən vænɪʃt ɪndə ðə ɹɑks wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ bæk.

"Then I will continue my search." It was not a question, yet Urien waited until she nodded before he eyed the Shienarans proudly, challengingly, then turned his back on them. He walked away smoothly, and vanished into the rocks without looking back.

səm ə ðə soʊlʒɝz bɪɡæn mʌɾɝɪŋ. ənoʊ sɛd sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt "kɹeɪzi blʌɾi il," ən mæsimə ɡɹaʊl ðət ðeɪ ʃʊɾə lɛf ði il fəɹ ðə ɹeɪvənz.

Some of the soldiers began muttering. Uno said something about "crazy bloody Aiel," and Masema growled that they should have left the Aiel for the ravens.

"wi hæv weɪstəd væljəbəl taɪm," ɪŋtʃɹ ənaʊns laʊdli. "wi wɪl ɹaɪd hɑɹɾɝ tə meɪk ɪɾ ʌp."

"We have wasted valuable time," Ingtar announced loudly. "We will ride harder to make it up."

"jɛs," vɛɹɪn sɛd, "wi mʌst ɹaɪd hɑɹɾɝ."

"Yes," Verin said, "we must ride harder."

ɪŋtʃɹ ɡlænst ət hɝ, bʌt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑz stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə smʌdʒd ɡɹaʊnd, wɛɹ əɹ fʊt hæɾ əblɪɾɝeɪtɪd ðə sɪmbəl. "dɪsmaʊnt," hi ɔɹɾɝd. "ɑɹmɝ ɑn ðə pækhɔɹsɪz. wɝ ɪnsaɪd kɛɹhin, naʊ. wi də nɑt wɑn ðə kɛɹhinɪn θɪŋkɪŋ wɪv kʌm tə faɪt ðɛm. bi kwɪk əbaʊɾ ɪt!"

Ingtar glanced at her, but the Aes Sedai was staring at the smudged ground, where her foot had obliterated the symbol. "Dismount," he ordered. "Armor on the packhorses. We're inside Cairhien, now. We do not want the Cairhienin thinking we have come to fight them. Be quick about it!"

mæt lin kloʊs tə pɛɹɪn. "du jə . . . ? dʒju θɪŋk i wɑz tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt ɹænd? ɪts kɹeɪzi, aɪ noʊ, bʌɾ ivən ɪŋtʃɹ θɪŋks hiz il."

Mat leaned close to Perrin. "Do you . . . ? Do you think he was talking about Rand? It's crazy, I know, but even Ingtar thinks he's Aiel."

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ɛvɹiθɪŋ əz bɪn kɹeɪzi sɪns wi ɡɑt mɪkst ʌp wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ."

"I don't know," Perrin said. "Everything has been crazy since we got mixed up with Aes Sedai."

sɔfli, əz tə hɝsɛlf, vɛɹɪn spoʊk, stɪl stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə ɡɹaʊnd. "ɪt mʌs bi ə pɑɹt, ən jɛt haʊ? dʌz ðə wil ə taɪm wiv θɹɛdz ɪndə ðə pæɾɝn ʌv wɪtʃ wi noʊ nʌθɪŋ? əɹ dʌz ðə dɑɹk wʌn tʌtʃ ðə pæɾɝn əɡɛn?"

Softly, as to herself, Verin spoke, still staring at the ground. "It must be a part, and yet how? Does the Wheel of Time weave threads into the Pattern of which we know nothing? Or does the Dark One touch the Pattern again?"

pɛɹɪn fɛlt ə tʃɪl.

Perrin felt a chill.

vɛɹɪn lʊkt ʌp ət ðə soʊlʒɝz ɹimuvɪŋ ðɛɹ ɑɹmɝ. "hɝi!" ʃi kəmændəd wɪð mɔɹ snæp ðən ɪŋtʃɹ ən ənoʊ kəmbaɪnd. "wi mʌs hɝi!"

Verin looked up at the soldiers removing their armor. "Hurry!" she commanded with more snap than Ingtar and Uno combined. "We must hurry!"


tʃæptɝ twɛntinaɪn


CHAPTER 29

sintʃæn


Seanchan

dʒɛəfɹæm bɔɹnhəld ɪɡnɔɹd ðə smɛl ə bɝnɪŋ haʊsəz ən ðə bɑɾiz ðət leɪ spɹɔld ɑn ðə dɝɾ ə ðə stʃɹit. baɪɑɝ ən ə waɪt-kloʊkt ɡɑɹɾ ʌv ə hʌnʒɹəd ɹoʊɾ ɪndə ðə vɪlədʒ əɾ ɪz hilz, hæf ðə mɛn i hæd wɪð hɪm. hɪz lidʒən wɑz tu skæɾɝd fəɹ ɪz laɪkɪŋ, wɪð kwɛstʃənɝz hævɪŋ tu mɛni ʌv ðə kəmænz, bʌɾ ɪz ɔɹɾɝz hæd bɪn ɪksplɪsət: oʊbeɪ ðə kwɛstʃənɝz.

Geofram Bornhald ignored the smell of burning houses and the bodies that lay sprawled on the dirt of the street. Byar and a white-cloaked guard of a hundred rode into the village at his heels, half the men he had with him. His legion was too scattered for his liking, with Questioners having too many of the commands, but his orders had been explicit: Obey the Questioners.

ðəɹ hæd bɪn bʌt slaɪt ɹɪzɪstəns hɪɹ; oʊnli hæf ə dʌzən dwɛlɪŋz ɡeɪv ɔf kɑləmz ə smoʊk. ði ɪn wɑz stɪl stændɪŋ, hi sɔ, waɪt-plæstɝd stoʊn laɪk ɔlmoʊst ɛvɹi stʃɹʌktʃɝ ɑn ɑlməθ pleɪn.

There had been but slight resistance here; only half a dozen dwellings gave off columns of smoke. The inn was still standing, he saw, white-plastered stone like almost every structure on Almoth Plain.

ɹeɪnɪŋ ʌp bɪfɔɹ ði ɪn, hɪz aɪz wɛn pæs ðə pɹɪznɝz ɪz soʊlʒɝz hɛl nɪɹ ðə vɪlədʒ wɛl tə ðə lɔŋ ɡɪbət mɑɹɪŋ ðə vɪlədʒ ɡɹin. ɪt wɑz heɪstəli meɪd, oʊnli ə lɔŋ poʊl ɑn ʌpɹaɪts, bʌɾ ɪt hɛl θɝɾi bɑɾiz, ðɛɹ kloʊðz ɹʌfəl baɪ ðə bɹiz. ðəɹ wɝ smɔl bɑɾiz hæŋɪŋ əmʌŋ ðɛɹ ɛldɝz. ivən baɪɑɝ stɛɹɾ ət ðəɾ ɪn dɪsbɪlif.

Reining up before the inn, his eyes went past the prisoners his soldiers held near the village well to the long gibbet marring the village green. It was hastily made, only a long pole on uprights, but it held thirty bodies, their clothes ruffled by the breeze. There were small bodies hanging among their elders. Even Byar stared at that in disbelief.

"muɔd!" hi ɹɔɹd. ə ɡɹɪzəl mæn tʃɹɑɾəd əweɪ fɹəm ðoʊz hoʊldɪŋ ðə pɹɪznɝz. muɔd hæd fɔlən ɪndə ðə hænz ə dɑɹkfɹɛnz, wʌns; hɪz skɑɹd feɪs tʊk ivən ðə stʃɹɔŋɡəst əbæk. "ɪz ðɪs jəɹ wɝk, muɔd, əɹ ðə sintʃæn?"

"Muadh!" he roared. A grizzled man trotted away from those holding the prisoners. Muadh had fallen into the hands of Darkfriends, once; his scarred face took even the strongest aback. "Is this your work, Muadh, or the Seanchan?"

"niðɝ, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən." muɔdz vɔɪs wɑz ə hɔɹs, wɪspɝd ɡɹaʊl, ənʌðɝ livɪŋ ə ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz. hi sɛd noʊ mɔɹ.

"Neither, my Lord Captain." Muadh's voice was a hoarse, whispered growl, another leaving of the Darkfriends. He said no more.

bɔɹnhəl fɹaʊnd. "ʃʊɹli ðət lɑt dɪd nɑt də ɪt," hi sɛd, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ tə ðə pɹɪznɝz. ðə tʃɪlʒɹən dɪd nɑt lʊk soʊ niɾ əz wən i hæd bɹɔɾ əm əkɹɔs tæɹɑbən, bʌt ðeɪ simd ɹɛɾi tə pɝeɪd kəmpɛɹd wɪð ðə ɹæbəl ðət kɹaʊtʃt ʌndɝ ðɛɹ wɑtʃfəl aɪz. mɛn ɪn ɹæɡz ən bɪts ʌv ɑɹmɝ, wɪð sʌlən feɪsəz. ɹɛmnəns ə ði ɑɹmi tæɹɑbən hæd sɛn əɡɛns ði ɪnveɪɾɝz ɑn toʊmən hɛd.

Bornhald frowned. "Surely that lot did not do it," he said, gesturing to the prisoners. The Children did not look so neat as when he had brought them across Tarabon, but they seemed ready to parade compared with the rabble that crouched under their watchful eyes. Men in rags and bits of armor, with sullen faces. Remnants of the army Tarabon had sent against the invaders on Toman Head.

muɔd hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən sɛd kɛɹfəli, "ðə vɪlɪdʒɝz seɪ ðeɪ wɔɹ tæɹɑbənɝ kloʊks, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən. ðəɹ wɑz ə bɪɡ mæn əmʌŋ ðɛm, wɪð ɡɹeɪ aɪz ən ə lɔŋ mʌstæʃ, ðət saʊnz twɪn tə tʃaɪld ɪɹwɪn, ən ə jʌŋ læd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə haɪɾ ə pɹɪɾi feɪs bɪhaɪn ə jɛloʊ bɪɹd, hu fɔt wɪð ɪz lɛf hænd. saʊnz ɔlmoʊs laɪk tʃaɪld wwɑn, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən."

Muadh hesitated, then said carefully, "The villagers say they wore Taraboner cloaks, my Lord Captain. There was a big man among them, with gray eyes and a long mustache, that sounds twin to Child Earwin, and a young lad, trying to hide a pretty face behind a yellow beard, who fought with his left hand. Sounds almost like Child Wuan, my Lord Captain."

"kwɛstʃənɝz!" bɔɹnhəl spæt. ɪɹwɪn ən wwɑn wɝ əmʌŋ ðoʊz i hæd hæd tə hæn oʊvɝ tə ðə kwɛstʃənɝz' kəmænd. hi hæd sin kwɛstʃənɝ tæktɪks bɪfɔɹ, bʌt ðɪs wɑz ðə fɝs taɪm i hæɾ ɛvɝ bɪn feɪst wɪð tʃɪlʒɹənz bɑɾiz.

"Questioners!" Bornhald spat. Earwin and Wuan were among those he had had to hand over to the Questioners' command. He had seen Questioner tactics before, but this was the first time he had ever been faced with children's bodies.

"ɪf maɪ lɔɹd kæptən sɛz soʊ." muɔd meɪɾ ɪt saʊn laɪk fɝvən əɡɹimənt.

"If my Lord Captain says so." Muadh made it sound like fervent agreement.

"kʌɾ əm daʊn," bɔɹnhəl sɛd wɛɹəli. "kʌɾ əm daʊn, ən meɪk ʃʊɹ ðə vɪlɪdʒɝz noʊ ðəɹ wɪl bi noʊ mɔɹ kɪlɪŋ." ənlɛs səm ful dɪsaɪdz tə bi bɹeɪv kəz ɪz wʊmən ɪz wɑtʃɪŋ, ən aɪ hæv tə meɪk ən ɪɡzæmpəl. hi dɪsmaʊntɪd, aɪɪŋ ðə pɹɪznɝz əɡɛn, əz muɔd hɝiɾ ɔf kɔlɪŋ fəɹ læɾɝz ən naɪvz. hi hæd mɔɹ tə θɪŋk əbaʊt ðən kwɛstʃənɝz' oʊvɝzɛləsnəs; hi wɪʃt i kəd stɑp θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt kwɛstʃənɝz ɔltəɡɛðɝ.

"Cut them down," Bornhald said wearily. "Cut them down, and make sure the villagers know there will be no more killing." Unless some fool decides to be brave because his woman is watching, and I have to make an example. He dismounted, eyeing the prisoners again, as Muadh hurried off calling for ladders and knives. He had more to think about than Questioners' overzealousness; he wished he could stop thinking about Questioners altogether.

"ðeɪ də nɑt pʊɾ ʌp mʌtʃ faɪt, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən," baɪɑɝ sɛd, "iðɝ ðiz tæɹɑbənɝz əɹ wʌɾ ɪz lɛft ə ðə dəmɑni. ðeɪ snæp laɪk kɔɹnɝd ɹæts, bʌt ɹʌn əz sun əz ɛniθɪŋ snæps bæk."

"They do not put up much fight, my Lord Captain," Byar said, "either these Taraboners or what is left of the Domani. They snap like cornered rats, but run as soon as anything snaps back."

"lɛɾ əs si haʊ wi də əɡɛns ði ɪnveɪɾɝz, baɪɑɝ, bɪfɔɹ wi lʊk daʊn ɑn ðiz mɛn, jɛs?" ðə pɹɪznɝz' feɪsəz bɔɹ ə dɪfiɾəd lʊk ðət hæd bɪn ðəɹ bɪfɔɹ ɪz mɛn keɪm. "hæv muɔd pɪk wʌn aʊt fəɹ mi." muɔdz feɪs wɑz ɪnʌf tə sɑfən moʊs mɛnz ɹizɑlv baɪ ɪtsɛlf. "æn ɔfəsɝ, pɹɛfɝəbli. wʌn u lʊks ɪntɛlədʒən ɪnʌf tə tɛl wʌt hiz sin wɪθaʊɾ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi, bʌt jʌŋ ɪnʌf nɑt tə hæv jɛt ɡɹoʊn ə fʊl bækboʊn. tɛl muɔd tə bi nɑt tu dʒɛntəl əbaʊɾ ɪt, jɛs? meɪk ðə fɛloʊ bɪliv ðəɾ aɪ min tə si wɝs hæpən tə hɪm ðən i ɛvɝ dʒɹimd ʌv, ənlɛs i kənvɪnsɪz mi ʌðɝwaɪz." hi tɔst ɪz ɹeɪnz tə wʌn ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ən stʃɹoʊɾ ɪndə ði ɪn.

"Let us see how we do against the invaders, Byar, before we look down on these men, yes?" The prisoners' faces bore a defeated look that had been there before his men came. "Have Muadh pick one out for me." Muadh's face was enough to soften most men's resolve by itself. "An officer, preferably. One who looks intelligent enough to tell what he has seen without embroidery, but young enough not to have yet grown a full backbone. Tell Muadh to be not too gentle about it, yes? Make the fellow believe that I mean to see worse happen to him than he ever dreamed of, unless he convinces me otherwise." He tossed his reins to one of the Children and strode into the inn.

ði ɪnkipɝ wɑz ðɛɹ, fəɹ ə wʌndɝ, ən əbsikwiəs, swɛɾɪŋ mæn, hɪz dɝɾi ʃɝt stʃɹeɪnɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz bɛli əntɪl ði ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɹɛd skɹɑlwɝk simd ɹɛɾi tə pɑp ɔf. bɔɹnhəld weɪv ðə mæn əweɪ; hi wɑz veɪɡli əwɛɹ ʌv ə wʊmən ən səm tʃɪlʒɹən hʌɾəlɪŋ ɪn ə dɔɹweɪ, əntɪl ðə fæɾ ɪnkipɝ ʃɛpɝɾɪd əm aʊt.

The innkeeper was there, for a wonder, an obsequious, sweating man, his dirty shirt straining over his belly until the embroidered red scrollwork seemed ready to pop off. Bornhald waved the man away; he was vaguely aware of a woman and some children huddling in a doorway, until the fat innkeeper shepherded them out.

bɔɹnhəl pʊld ɔf ɪz ɡɔnləts ən sæɾ ət wʌn ə ðə teɪbəlz. hi nu tu lɪɾəl əbaʊt ði ɪnveɪɾɝz, ðə stʃɹeɪnʒɝz. ðət wɑz wʌɾ ɔlmoʊst ɛvɹiwʌn kɔl ðɛm, ðoʊz u dɪd nɑt dʒʌs bæbəl əbaʊɾ ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ. hi nu ðeɪ kɔl ðɛmsɛlvz ðə sintʃæn, ən heɪlin. hi hæɾ ɪnʌf ə ði oʊl tʌŋ tə noʊ ðə læɾɝ mɛn ðoʊz u kʌm bɪfɔɹ, əɹ ðə fɔɹʌnɝz. ðeɪ ɔlsoʊ kɔl ðɛmsɛlvz ɹaɪædʒɛl, ðoʊz u kʌm hoʊm, ən spoʊk ə kɔɝɪn, ðə ɹɪtɝn. ɪt wɑz ɔlmoʊst ɪnʌf tə meɪk ɪm bɪliv ðə teɪlz ʌv ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz ɑɹmiz kʌm bæk. noʊ wʌn nu wɛɹ ðə sintʃæn hæd kʌm fɹʌm, ʌðɝ ðən ðət ðeɪ hæd lændəɾ ɪn ʃɪps. bɔɹnhəlz ɹɪkwɛsts fəɹ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən fɹəm ðə si foʊk hæd bɪn mɛt wɪð saɪləns. æmədɔɹ dɪd nɑt hoʊl ði æθɑn maɪɹ ɪn ɡʊd feɪvɝ, ən ði æɾətud wɑz ɹɪtɝnd wɪð ɪntʃɹəst. ɔl i nu ʌv ðə sintʃæn i hæd hɝd fɹəm mɛn laɪk ðoʊz aʊtsaɪd. bɹoʊkən, biɾən ɹæbəl u spoʊk, waɪd-aɪɾ ən swɛɾɪŋ, ʌv mɛn u keɪm ɪndə bæɾəl ɹaɪɾɪŋ mɑnstɝz əz ɔfən əz hɔɹsəz, hu fɔt wɪð mɑnstɝz baɪ ðɛɹ saɪdz, ən bɹɔɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ tə ɹɛn ði ɝθ ʌndɝ ðɛɹ ɛnəmiz' fit.

Bornhald pulled off his gauntlets and sat at one of the tables. He knew too little about the invaders, the strangers. That was what almost everyone called them, those who did not just babble about Artur Hawkwing. He knew they called themselves the Seanchan, and Hailene. He had enough of the Old Tongue to know the latter meant Those Who Come Before, or the Forerunners. They also called themselves Rhyagelle, Those Who Come Home, and spoke of Corenne, the Return. It was almost enough to make him believe the tales of Artur Hawkwing's armies come back. No one knew where the Seanchan had come from, other than that they had landed in ships. Bornhald's requests for information from the Sea Folk had been met with silence. Amador did not hold the Atha'an Miere in good favor, and the attitude was returned with interest. All he knew of the Seanchan he had heard from men like those outside. Broken, beaten rabble who spoke, wide-eyed and sweating, of men who came into battle riding monsters as often as horses, who fought with monsters by their sides, and brought Aes Sedai to rend the earth under their enemies' feet.

ə saʊn ə buts ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ meɪɾ ɪm pʊɾ ɑn ə wʊlfɪʃ ɡɹɪn, bʌt baɪɑɝ wɑz nɑɾ əkʌmpənid baɪ muɔd. ðə tʃaɪld ə ðə laɪɾ u stʊd bɪsaɪd hɪm, bæk bɹeɪst ən hɛlməɾ ɪn ðə kɹʊk ə hɪz ɑɹm, wɑz dʒɛɹəl, hu bɔɹnhəld ɪkspɛktəd tə bi ə hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz əweɪ. oʊvɝ ɪz ɑɹmɝ, ðə jʌŋ mæn wɔɹ ə kloʊk ə dəmɑni kʌt, tʃɹɪmd wɪð blu, nɑt ðə waɪt kloʊk ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən.

A sound of boots in the doorway made him put on a wolfish grin, but Byar was not accompanied by Muadh. The Child of the Light who stood beside him, back braced and helmet in the crook of his arm, was Jeral, who Bornhald expected to be a hundred miles away. Over his armor, the young man wore a cloak of Domani cut, trimmed with blue, not the white cloak of the Children.

"muɔɾ ɪz tɔkɪŋ tə ə jʌŋ fɛloʊ naʊ, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən," baɪɑɝ sɛd. "tʃaɪl dʒɛɹəl əz dʒʌst ɹɪɾən ɪn wɪð ə mɛsədʒ."

"Muadh is talking to a young fellow now, my Lord Captain," Byar said. "Child Jeral has just ridden in with a message."

bɔɹnhəld weɪv fəɹ dʒɛɹəl tə bɪɡɪn.

Bornhald waved for Jeral to begin.

ðə jʌŋ mæn dɪd nɑɾ ʌnbɪnd. "ðə kɑmpləməns ə dʒeɪitʃɪm kæɹaɪɾɪn," hi stɑɹɾəd, lʊkɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛd, "hu ɡaɪdz ðə hæn ə ðə laɪɾ ɪn - "

The young man did not unbend. "The compliments of Jaichim Carridin," he started, looking straight ahead, "who guides the Hand of the Light in - "

"aɪ hæv noʊ niɾ ə ðə kwɛstʃənɝz kɑmpləməns," bɔɹnhəld ɡɹaʊld, ən sɔ ðə jʌŋ mænz stɑɹɾəld lʊk. dʒɛɹəl wɑz jʌŋ, jɛt. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, baɪɑɝ lʊkt ənkʌmftəɹbəl, əz wɛl. "ju wɪl ɡɪmi hɪz mɛsədʒ, jɛs? nɑt wɝd fəɹ wɝd, ənlɛs aɪ æsk ɪt. sɪmpli tɛl mi wʌɾ i wɑns."

"I have no need of the Questioner's compliments," Bornhald growled, and saw the young man's startled look. Jeral was young, yet. For that matter, Byar looked uncomfortable, as well. "You will give me his message, yes? Not word for word, unless I ask it. Simply tell me what he wants."

ðə tʃaɪld, sɛt tə ɹəsaɪt, swɑloʊd bɪfɔɹ i bɪɡæn. "maɪ lɔɹd kæptən, hi - hi sɛz jə ɑɹ muvɪŋ tu mɛni mɛn tu kloʊs tə toʊmən hɛd. hi sɛz ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz ɑn ɑlməθ pleɪn mʌs bi ɹuɾəd aʊt, ən jə ɑɹ - fɝɡɪv mi, lɔɹd kæptən - jə ɑɹ tə tɝn bæk ət wʌns ən ɹaɪd təwɔɹd ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə pleɪn." hi stʊd stɪfli, weɪɾɪŋ.

The Child, set to recite, swallowed before he began. "My Lord Captain, he - he says you are moving too many men too close to Toman Head. He says the Darkfriends on Almoth Plain must be rooted out, and you are - forgive me, Lord Captain - you are to turn back at once and ride toward the heart of the plain." He stood stiffly, waiting.

bɔɹnhəl stʌɾid hɪm. ðə dʌst ə ðə pleɪn steɪn dʒɛɹəlz feɪs əz wɛl əz ɪz kloʊk ən ɪz buts. "ɡoʊ ən ɡɛt jɝsɛlf sʌmθɪŋ tə it," bɔɹn-hɔl toʊl hɪm. "ðɛɹ ʃəd bi wɑʃ wɔɾɝ ɪn wʌn ə ðiz haʊsəz, ɪf jə wɪʃ ɪt. ɹɪtɝn tə mi ɪn ən aʊɝ. əl əv mɛsədʒəz fəɹ jə tə kæɹi." hi weɪv ðə jʌŋ mæn aʊt.

Bornhald studied him. The dust of the plain stained Jeral's face as well as his cloak and his boots. "Go and get yourself something to eat," Born-hald told him. "There should be wash water in one of these houses, if you wish it. Return to me in an hour. I will have messages for you to carry." He waved the young man out.

"ðə kwɛstʃənɝz meɪ bi ɹaɪt, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən," baɪɑɝ sɛd wən dʒɛɹəl wɑz ɡɔn. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ mɛni vɪlədʒəz skæɾɝd ɑn ðə pleɪn, ən ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz - "

"The Questioners may be right, my Lord Captain," Byar said when Jeral was gone. "There are many villages scattered on the plain, and the Darkfriends - "

bɔɹnhəlz hæn slæpɪŋ ðə teɪbəl kʌɾ ɪm ɔf. "wʌt dɑɹkfɹɛnz? aɪ hæv sin nʌθɪŋ ɪn ɛni vɪlədʒ hiz ɔɹɾɝd teɪkən ɪksɛp fɑɹmɝz ən kɹæfsmən wɝid ðət wɪl bɝn ðɛɹ lɪvəlɪhʊdz, ən ə fju oʊld wɪmən u tɛn ðə sɪk." baɪɑɝz feɪs wɑz ə stʌɾi ɪn læk ʌv ɪkspɹɛʃən; hi wɑz ɔlweɪz ɹɛɾiɝ ðən bɔɹnhəl tə si dɑɹkfɹɛnz. "æn tʃɪlʒɹən, baɪɑɝ? də tʃɪlʒɹən hɪɹ bɪkʌm dɑɹkfɹɛnz?"

Bornhald's hand slapping the table cut him off. "What Darkfriends? I have seen nothing in any village he has ordered taken except farmers and craftsmen worried that we will burn their livelihoods, and a few old women who tend the sick." Byar's face was a study in lack of expression; he was always readier than Bornhald to see Darkfriends. "And children, Byar? Do children here become Darkfriends?"

"ðə sɪnz ə ðə mʌðɝ ɑɹ vɪzəɾəd tə ðə fɪfθ dʒɛnɝeɪʃən," baɪɑɝ kwoʊɾəd, "æn ðə sɪnz ə ðə fɑðɝ tə ðə tɛnθ." bʌɾ i lʊkt ənizi. ivən baɪɑɝ hæd nɛvɝ kɪld ə tʃaɪld.

"The sins of the mother are visited to the fifth generation," Byar quoted, "and the sins of the father to the tenth." But he looked uneasy. Even Byar had never killed a child.

"hæz ɪt nɛvɝ əkɝd tə ju, baɪɑɝ, tə wʌndɝ waɪ kæɹaɪɾɪn əz teɪkən əweɪ əɹ bænɝz, ən ðə kloʊks ə ðə mɛn ðə kwɛstʃənɝz lɛd? ivən ðə kwɛstʃənɝz ðɛmsɛlvz əv pʊɾ ɔf ðə waɪt. ðɪs sədʒɛsts sʌmθɪŋ, jɛs?"

"Has it never occurred to you, Byar, to wonder why Carridin has taken away our banners, and the cloaks of the men the Questioners lead? Even the Questioners themselves have put off the white. This suggests something, yes?"

"hi mʌst əv ɪz ɹizənz, lɔɹd kæptən," baɪɑɝ sɛd sloʊli. "ðə kwɛstʃənɝz ɔlweɪz əv ɹizənz, ivən wən ðeɪ də nɑt tɛl ðə ɹɛst ʌv ʌs."

"He must have his reasons, Lord Captain," Byar said slowly. "The Questioners always have reasons, even when they do not tell the rest of us."

bɔɹnhəld ɹimaɪndəd hɪmsɛlf ðət baɪɑɝ wɑz ə ɡʊd soʊlʒɝ. "tʃɪlʒɹən tə ðə nɔɹθ wɛɹ tæɹɑbənɝ kloʊks, baɪɑɝ, ən ðoʊz tə ðə saʊθ dəmɑni. aɪ də nɑt laɪk wʌt ðɪs sədʒɛsts tə mi. ðəɹ ɑɹ dɑɹkfɹɛnz hɪɹ, bʌt ðeɪ ɑɹ ɪn fɑlm, nɑɾ ɑn ðə pleɪn. wən dʒɛɹəl ɹaɪdz, hɪl nɑt ɹaɪɾ əloʊn. mɛsədʒəz wɪl ɡoʊ tə ɛvɹi ɡɹup ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən aɪ noʊ haʊ tə faɪnd. aɪ min tə teɪk ðə lidʒən ɑntu toʊmən hɛd, baɪɑɝ, ən si wʌt ðə tʃɹu dɑɹkfɹɛnz, ðiz sintʃæn, ɑɹ ʌp tə."

Bornhald reminded himself that Byar was a good soldier. "Children to the north wear Taraboner cloaks, Byar, and those to the south Domani. I do not like what this suggests to me. There are Darkfriends here, but they are in Falme, not on the plain. When Jeral rides, he will not ride alone. Messages will go to every group of the Children I know how to find. I mean to take the legion onto Toman Head, Byar, and see what the true Darkfriends, these Seanchan, are up to."

baɪɑɝ lʊk tʃɹʌbəld, bʌt bɪfɔɹ i kəd spik, muɔɾ əpɪɹd wɪð wʌn ə ðə pɹɪznɝz. ðə swɛɾɪŋ jʌŋ mæn ɪn ə bæɾɝd, ɔɹneɪt bɹɛstpleɪt ʃɑt fɹaɪɾənd lʊks ət muɔdz hɪɾiəs feɪs.

Byar looked troubled, but before he could speak, Muadh appeared with one of the prisoners. The sweating young man in a battered, ornate breastplate shot frightened looks at Muadh's hideous face.

bɔɹnhəl dʒɹu hɪz dæɡɝ ən bɪɡæn tʃɹɪmɪŋ ɪz neɪlz. hi hæd nɛvɝ ʌndɝstʊd waɪ ðət meɪd səm mɛn nɝvəs, bʌɾ i juzd ɪt dʒʌs ðə seɪm. ivən ɪz ɡɹændfɑðɝli smaɪl meɪd ðə pɹɪznɝz dɝɾi feɪs peɪl. "naʊ, jʌŋ mæn, jəl tɛl mi ɛvɹiθɪŋ jə noʊ əbaʊt ðiz stʃɹeɪnʒɝz, jɛs? ɪf jə nid tə θɪŋk ɑn wʌt tə seɪ, əl sɛn jə bæk aʊt wɪð tʃaɪl muɔd tə kənsɪɾɝ ɪt."

Bornhald drew his dagger and began trimming his nails. He had never understood why that made some men nervous, but he used it just the same. Even his grandfatherly smile made the prisoner's dirty face pale. "Now, young man, you will tell me everything you know about these strangers, yes? If you need to think on what to say, I will send you back out with Child Muadh to consider it."

ðə pɹɪznɝ dɑɹɾɪd ə waɪd-aɪd lʊk ət muɔd. ðən wɝdz bɪɡæn tə pɔɹ aʊɾ ə hɪm.

The prisoner darted a wide-eyed look at Muadh. Then words began to pour out of him.

ðə lɔŋ swɛlz ə ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən meɪd spɹeɪ ɹoʊl, bʌt doʊmənz spɹɛd fit bælənst ɪm əz i hɛl ðə lɔŋ tub ə ðə lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs tə hɪz aɪ ən stʌɾid ðə lɑɹdʒ vɛsəl ðət pɝsud ðɛm. pɝsud, ən wɑz sloʊli oʊvɝteɪkɪŋ. ðə wɪnd wɛɹ spɹeɪ ɹæn wɑz nɑt ðə bɛst əɹ ðə stʃɹɔŋɡəst, bʌt wɛɹ ði ʌðɝ ʃɪp smæʃt ðə swɛlz ɪndə maʊntənz ə foʊm wɪð ɪts blʌf baʊ, ɪt kəd nɑɾ əv bloʊn bɛɾɝ. ðə koʊstlaɪn ə toʊmən hɛd lum tə ði ist, dɑɹk klɪfs ən nɛɹoʊ stʃɹɪps ə sænd. hi hæd nɑt kɛɹd tə teɪk spɹeɪ tu fɑɹ aʊt, ən naʊ hi fɪɹɾ i maɪt peɪ fəɹ ɪt.

The long swells of the Aryth Ocean made Spray roll, but Domon's spread feet balanced him as he held the long tube of the looking glass to his eye and studied the large vessel that pursued them. Pursued, and was slowly overtaking. The wind where Spray ran was not the best or the strongest, but where the other ship smashed the swells into mountains of foam with its bluff bow, it could not have blown better. The coastline of Toman Head loomed to the east, dark cliffs and narrow strips of sand. He had not cared to take Spray too far out, and now he feared he might pay for it.

"stʃɹeɪnʒɝz, kæptən?" jɑɹən hæd ðə saʊn ə swɛɾ ɪn ɪz vɔɪs. "ɪz ɪɾ ə stʃɹeɪnʒɝz' ʃɪp?"

"Strangers, Captain?" Yarin had the sound of sweat in his voice. "Is it a strangers' ship?"

doʊmən loʊɝd ðə lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs, bʌɾ ɪz aɪ stɪl sim fɪl baɪ ðət tɔl, skwɛɹ-lʊkɪŋ ʃɪp wɪð ɪts ɑd ɹɪb seɪlz. "sintʃæn," hi sɛd, ən hɝd jɑɹən ɡɹoʊn. hi dʒɹʌmd ɪz θɪk fɪŋɡɝz ɑn ðə ɹeɪl, ðən toʊl ðə hɛlmzmæn, "teɪk əɹ kloʊsɝ ɪn. ðət ʃɪp wɪl noʊ dɛɹ ɛntɝ ðə ʃæloʊ wɔɾɝz spɹeɪ kən seɪl."

Domon lowered the looking glass, but his eye still seemed filled by that tall, square-looking ship with its odd ribbed sails. "Seanchan," he said, and heard Yarin groan. He drummed his thick fingers on the rail, then told the helmsman, "Take her closer in. That ship will no dare enter the shallow waters Spray can sail."

jɑɹən ʃaʊɾəd kəmænz, ən kɹumɪn ɹæn tə hɔl ɪn bumz əz ðə hɛlmzmæn pʊt ðə tɪlɝ oʊvɝ, pɔɪntɪŋ ðə baʊ mɔɹ təwɔɹd ðə ʃɔɹlaɪn. spɹeɪ muv mɔɹ sloʊli, hɛɾɪŋ soʊ fɑɹ ɪndə ðə wɪnd, bʌt doʊmən wɑz ʃʊɹ i kəd ɹitʃ ʃoʊl wɔɾɝz bɪfɔɹ ði ʌðɝ vɛsəl keɪm ʌp ɑn hɪm. dɪɾ əɹ hoʊlz bi fʊl, ʃi kəd stɪl teɪk ʃæloʊɝ wɔɾɝ ðən ɛvɝ ðət ɡɹeɪt hʌl kæn.

Yarin shouted commands, and crewmen ran to haul in booms as the helmsman put the tiller over, pointing the bow more toward the shoreline. Spray moved more slowly, heading so far into the wind, but Domon was sure he could reach shoal waters before the other vessel came up on him. Did her holds be full, she could still take shallower water than ever that great hull can.

hɪz ʃɪp ɹoʊɾ ə lɪɾəl haɪɝ ɪn ðə wɔɾɝ ðən ʃi hæɾ ɑn seɪlɪŋ fɹəm tæntʃəkoʊ. ə θɝɾ ə ðə kɑɹɡoʊ ʌv faɪɹwɝks i hæd teɪkən ɑn ðəɹ wɑz ɡɔn, soʊld ɪn ðə fɪʃɪŋ vɪlədʒəz ɑn toʊmən hɛd, bʌt wɪð ðə sɪlvɝ ðət floʊd fəɹ ðə faɪɹwɝks hæd kʌm dɪstɝbɪŋ ɹɪpɔɹts. ðə pipəl spoʊk ə vɪzəts fɹəm ðə tɔl, bɑksi ʃɪps ə ði ɪnveɪɾɝz. wən sintʃæn ʃɪps æŋkɝɾ ɔf ðə koʊst, ðə vɪlɪdʒɝz u dʒɹu ʌp tə dɪfɛn ðɛɹ hoʊmz wɝ ɹɛn baɪ laɪtnɪŋ fɹəm ðə skaɪ waɪl smɔl boʊts wɝ stɪl fɛɹiɪŋ ði ɪnveɪɾɝz əʃɔɹ, ən ði ɝθ ɪɹʌptəɾ ɪn faɪɝ ʌndɝ ðɛɹ fit. doʊmən hæd θɔɾ i wɑz hɪɹɪŋ nɑnsɛns əntɪl i wɑz ʃoʊn ðə blækənd ɡɹaʊnd, ən i hæd sin ɪɾ ɪn tu mɛni vɪlədʒəz tə daʊɾ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. mɑnstɝz fɔt bɪsaɪd ðə sintʃæn soʊlʒɝz, nɑt ðət ðəɹ wɑz ɛvɝ mʌtʃ ɹɪzɪstəns lɛft, ðə vɪlɪdʒɝz sɛd, ən səm ivən kleɪm ðət ðə sintʃæn ðɛmsɛlvz wɝ mɑnstɝz, wɪð hɛdz laɪk hjudʒ ɪnsɛks.

His ship rode a little higher in the water than she had on sailing from Tanchico. A third of the cargo of fireworks he had taken on there was gone, sold in the fishing villages on Toman Head, but with the silver that flowed for the fireworks had come disturbing reports. The people spoke of visits from the tall, boxy ships of the invaders. When Seanchan ships anchored off the coast, the villagers who drew up to defend their homes were rent by lightning from the sky while small boats were still ferrying the invaders ashore, and the earth erupted in fire under their feet. Domon had thought he was hearing nonsense until he was shown the blackened ground, and he had seen it in too many villages to doubt any longer. Monsters fought beside the Seanchan soldiers, not that there was ever much resistance left, the villagers said, and some even claimed that the Seanchan themselves were monsters, with heads like huge insects.

ɪn tæntʃəkoʊ, noʊ wʌn hæɾ ivən noʊn wʌt ðeɪ kɔl ðɛmsɛlvz, ən ðə tæɹɑbənɝz spoʊk kɑnfəɾəntli ʌv ðɛɹ soʊlʒɝz dʒɹaɪvɪŋ ði ɪnveɪɾɝz ɪndə ðə si. bʌɾ ɪn ɛvɹi koʊstəl taʊn, ɪt wɑz dɪfɹənt. ðə sintʃæn toʊld əstɑnɪʃt pipəl ðeɪ mʌst swɛɹ əɡɛn oʊðz ðeɪ hæd fɔɹseɪkən, ðoʊ nɛvɝ dɪnɪŋ tə ɪkspleɪn wən ðeɪ hæd fɔɹseɪkən ðɛm, əɹ wʌt ði oʊðz mɛnt. ðə jʌŋ wɪmən wɝ teɪkən əweɪ wʌn baɪ wʌn tə bi ɪɡzæmənd, ən səm wɝ kæɹiɾ əbɔɹd ðə ʃɪps ən nɛvɝ sin əɡɛn. ə fju oʊldɝ wɪmən hæɾ ɔlsoʊ vænɪʃt, səm ə ðə ɡaɪdz ən hilɝz. nu meɪɝz wɝ tʃoʊzən baɪ ðə sintʃæn, ən nu kaʊnsəlz, ən ɛni hu pɹətɛstəd ðə dɪsəpɪɹənsɪz ə ðə wɪmən əɹ hævɪŋ noʊ vɔɪs ɪn ðə tʃuzɪŋ maɪt bi hʌŋ, əɹ bɝst sʌɾənli ɪndə fleɪm, əɹ bi bɹʌʃt əsaɪd laɪk jæpɪŋ dɑɡz. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ ʌv tɛlɪŋ wɪtʃ ɪt wəd bi əntɪl ɪt wɑz tu leɪt.

In Tanchico, no one had even known what they called themselves, and the Taraboners spoke confidently of their soldiers driving the invaders into the sea. But in every coastal town, it was different. The Seanchan told astonished people they must swear again oaths they had forsaken, though never deigning to explain when they had forsaken them, or what the oaths meant. The young women were taken away one by one to be examined, and some were carried aboard the ships and never seen again. A few older women had also vanished, some of the Guides and Healers. New mayors were chosen by the Seanchan, and new Councils, and any who protested the disappearances of the women or having no voice in the choosing might be hung, or burst suddenly into flame, or be brushed aside like yapping dogs. There was no way of telling which it would be until it was too late.

ən wən ðə pipəl hæd bɪn θɝoʊli kaʊd, wən ðeɪ hæd bɪn meɪd tə nil ən swɛɹ, bɪwɪldɝd, tə oʊbeɪ ðə fɔɹʌnɝz, əweɪt ðə ɹɪtɝn, ən sɝv ðoʊz u kʌm hoʊm wɪð ðɛɹ lɪvz, ðə sintʃæn seɪld əweɪ ən juʒəwəli nɛvɝ ɹɪtɝnd. fɑlm, ɪt wɑz sɛd, wɑz ði oʊnli taʊn ðeɪ hɛl fæst.

And when the people had been thoroughly cowed, when they had been made to kneel and swear, bewildered, to obey the Forerunners, await the Return, and serve Those Who Come Home with their lives, the Seanchan sailed away and usually never returned. Falme, it was said, was the only town they held fast.

ɪn səm ə ðə vɪlədʒəz ðeɪ hæd lɛft, mɛn ən wɪmən kɹɛp bæk təwɔɹd ðɛɹ fɔɹmɝ laɪvz, tə ði ɪkstɛn ə tɔkɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪlɛktɪŋ ðɛɹ kaʊnsəlz əɡɛn, bʌt moʊst aɪd ðə si nɝvəsli ən meɪd peɪl-tʃik pɹoʊɾɛsts ðət ðeɪ mɛn tə hoʊl tə ði oʊðz ðeɪ hæd bɪn meɪd tə swɛɹ ivən ɪf ðeɪ dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ðɛm.

In some of the villages they had left, men and women crept back toward their former lives, to the extent of talking about electing their Councils again, but most eyed the sea nervously and made pale-cheeked protests that they meant to hold to the oaths they had been made to swear even if they did not understand them.

doʊmən hæd noʊ ɪntɛntʃən ə miɾɪŋ ɛni sintʃæn, ɪf i kəɾ əvɔɪɾ ɪt.

Domon had no intention of meeting any Seanchan, if he could avoid it.

hi wɑz ɹeɪzɪŋ ðə ɡlæs tə si wʌɾ i kəd meɪk aʊɾ ɑn ðə nɪɹɪŋ sintʃæn dɛks, wɛn, wɪð ə ɹɔɹ, ðə sɝfəs ə ðə si bɹoʊk ɪndə faʊnteɪnɪŋ wɔɾɝ ən fleɪm nɑɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz fɹəm ɪz lɑɹbɔɹd saɪd. bɪfɔɹ i hæɾ ivən bɪɡʌn tə ɡeɪp, ənʌðɝ kɑləm ə fleɪm splɪt ðə si ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd, ən əz i wɑz spɪnɪŋ tə stɛɹ ət ðæt, ənʌðɝ bɝst ʌp əhɛd. ði ɪɹʌpʃənz daɪɾ əz kwɪkli əz ðeɪ wɝ bɔɹn, spɹeɪ fɹəm əm bloʊn əkɹɔs ðə dɛk. wɛɹ ðeɪ hæd bɪn, ðə si bʌbəld ən stimd əz ɪf bɔɪlɪŋ.

He was raising the glass to see what he could make out on the nearing Seanchan decks, when, with a roar, the surface of the sea broke into fountaining water and flame not a hundred paces from his larboard side. Before he had even begun to gape, another column of flame split the sea on the other side, and as he was spinning to stare at that, another burst up ahead. The eruptions died as quickly as they were born, spray from them blown across the deck. Where they had been, the sea bubbled and steamed as if boiling.

"wi . . . wɪl ɹitʃ ʃæloʊ wɔɾɝ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ kən kloʊz wɪð ʌs," jɑɹən sɛd sloʊli. hi sim tə bi tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑt tə lʊk ət ðə wɔɾɝ ɹɔɪlɪŋ ʌndɝ klaʊdz ə mɪst.

"We . . . we'll reach shallow water before they can close with us," Yarin said slowly. He seemed to be trying not to look at the water roiling under clouds of mist.

doʊmən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "wʌtɛvɝ ðeɪ dɪd, ðeɪ kən ʃæɾɝ ʌs, ivən də aɪ teɪk əɹ ɪndə ðə bɹeɪkɝz." hi ʃɪvɝd, θɪŋkɪŋ ə ðə fleɪm ɪnsaɪd ðə faʊntənz ʌv wɔɾɝ, ən ɪz hoʊlz fʊl ə faɪɹwɝks. "fɔɹtʃən pɹɪk mi, wi maɪt noʊ lɪv tə dʒɹaʊn." hi tʌɡd əɾ ɪz bɪɹɾ ən ɹʌbd ɪz bɛɹ ʌpɝ lɪp, ɹɪlʌktən tə ɡɪv ði ɔɹɾɝ - ðə vɛsəl ən wʌɾ ɪt kənteɪnd wɝ ɔl i hæɾ ɪn ðə wɝld - bʌt faɪnəli hi meɪd hɪmsɛlf spik. "bɹɪŋ əɹ ɪndə ðə wɪnd, jɑɹən, ən daʊn seɪl. kwɪkli, mæn, kwɪkli! bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ də θɪŋk wi stɪl tʃɹaɪ tə ɪskeɪp."

Domon shook his head. "Whatever they did, they can shatter us, even do I take her into the breakers." He shivered, thinking of the flame inside the fountains of water, and his holds full of fireworks. "Fortune prick me, we might no live to drown." He tugged at his beard and rubbed his bare upper lip, reluctant to give the order - the vessel and what it contained were all he had in the world - but finally he made himself speak. "Bring her into the wind, Yarin, and down sail. Quickly, man, quickly! Before they do think we still try to escape."

əz kɹumɪn ɹæn tə loʊɝ ðə tʃɹaɪæŋɡjəlɝ seɪlz, doʊmən tɝn tə wɑtʃ ðə sintʃæn ʃɪp əpɹoʊtʃ. spɹeɪ lɔs hɛdweɪ ən pɪtʃt ɪn ðə swɛlz. ði ʌðɝ vɛsəl stʊd tɔlɝ əbʌv ðə wɔɾɝ ðən doʊmənz ʃɪp, wɪð wʊɾən taʊɝz ət baʊ ən stɝn. mɛn wɝ ɪn ðə ɹɪɡɪŋ, ɹeɪzɪŋ ðoʊz stʃɹeɪnʒ seɪlz, ən ɑɹmɝd fɪɡjɝz stʊɾ ətɑp ðə taʊɝz. ə lɔŋboʊt wɑz pʊɾ oʊvɝ ðə saɪd, ən spɛd təwɔɹd spɹeɪ ʌndɝ tɛn ɔɹz. ɪt kæɹiɾ ɑɹmɝd ʃeɪps, ən - doʊmən fɹaʊn ɪn sɝpɹaɪz - tu wɪmən kɹaʊtʃt ɪn ðə stɝn. ðə lɔŋboʊt θʌmpt əɡɛnst spɹeɪz hʌl.

As crewmen ran to lower the triangular sails, Domon turned to watch the Seanchan ship approach. Spray lost headway and pitched in the swells. The other vessel stood taller above the water than Domon's ship, with wooden towers at bow and stern. Men were in the rigging, raising those strange sails, and armored figures stood atop the towers. A longboat was put over the side, and sped toward Spray under ten oars. It carried armored shapes, and - Domon frowned in surprise - two women crouched in the stern. The longboat thumped against Spray's hull.

ðə fɝs tə klaɪm ʌp wɑz wʌn ə ði ɑɹmɝd mɛn, ən doʊmən sɔ ɪmiɾiətli waɪ səm ə ðə vɪlɪdʒɝz kleɪm ðə sintʃæn ðɛmsɛlvz wɝ mɑnstɝz. ðə hɛlmət lʊk vɛɹi mʌtʃ laɪk səm mɑnstʃɹəs ɪnsɛks hɛd, wɪð θɪn ɹɛd plumz laɪk filɝz; ðə wɛɹɝ sim tə bi piɹɪŋ aʊt θɹu mændəbəlz. ɪt wɑz peɪntəɾ ən ɡɪldɪd tə ɪnkɹis ði ɪfɛkt, ən ðə ɹɛst ə ðə mænz ɑɹmɝ wɑz ɔlsoʊ wɝkt wɪð peɪn ən ɡoʊld. oʊvɝlæpɪŋ pleɪts ɪn blæk ən ɹɛɾ aʊtlaɪnd wɪð ɡoʊl kʌvɝɾ ɪz tʃɛst ən ɹæn daʊn ði aʊtsaɪdz ə hɪz ɑɹmz ən ðə fɹʌns ə hɪz θaɪz. ivən ðə stil bæks ə hɪz ɡɔnləts wɝ ɹɛɾ ən ɡoʊld. wɛɹ i dɪd nɑt wɛɹ mɛɾəl, hɪz kloʊðz wɝ dɑɹk lɛðɝ. ðə tu-hændəd sɔɹɾ ɑn ɪz bæk, wɪð ɪts kɝv bleɪd, wɑz skæbɑɹɾɪd ən hɪltɪɾ ɪn blæk-ænd-ɹɛd lɛðɝ.

The first to climb up was one of the armored men, and Domon saw immediately why some of the villagers claimed the Seanchan themselves were monsters. The helmet looked very much like some monstrous insect's head, with thin red plumes like feelers; the wearer seemed to be peering out through mandibles. It was painted and gilded to increase the effect, and the rest of the man's armor was also worked with paint and gold. Overlapping plates in black and red outlined with gold covered his chest and ran down the outsides of his arms and the fronts of his thighs. Even the steel backs of his gauntlets were red and gold. Where he did not wear metal, his clothes were dark leather. The two-handed sword on his back, with its curved blade, was scabbarded and hilted in black-and-red leather.

ðən ði ɑɹmɝd fɪɡjɝ ɹimuvd ɪz hɛlmət, ən doʊmən stɛɹd. hi wɑz ə wʊmən. hɝ dɑɹk hɛɹ wɑz kʌt ʃɔɹt, ən əɹ feɪs wɑz hɑɹd, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ mɪsteɪkɪŋ ɪt. hi hæd nɛvɝ hɝɾ ə sətʃ ə θɪŋ, ɪksɛpt əmʌŋ ði il, ən il wɝ wɛl noʊn tə bi kɹeɪzd. dʒʌst əz dɪskənsɝɾɪŋ wɑz ðə fæk ðəɾ əɹ feɪs dɪd nɑt lʊk əz dɪfɹən əz i hæɾ ɪkspɛktəɾ ʌv ə sintʃæn. hɝ aɪz wɝ blu, ɪt wɑz tʃɹu, ən əɹ skɪn ɪksiɾɪŋli fɛɹ, bʌɾ i hæd sin boʊθ bɪfɔɹ. ɪf ðɪs wʊmən wɔɹ ə dʒɹɛs, noʊ wʌn wəd lʊk əɾ əɹ twaɪs. hi aɪɾ əɹ ən ɹɪvaɪzd ɪz əpɪnjən, ðət koʊl stɛɹ ən ðoʊz hɑɹd tʃiks wəd meɪk əɹ ɹɪmɑɹkt ɛniwɛɹ.

Then the armored figure removed his helmet, and Domon stared. He was a woman. Her dark hair was cut short, and her face was hard, but there was no mistaking it. He had never heard of such a thing, except among the Aiel, and Aiel were well known to be crazed. Just as disconcerting was the fact that her face did not look as different as he had expected of a Seanchan. Her eyes were blue, it was true, and her skin exceedingly fair, but he had seen both before. If this woman wore a dress, no one would look at her twice. He eyed her and revised his opinion, that cold stare and those hard cheeks would make her remarked anywhere.

ði ʌðɝ soʊlʒɝz fɑloʊd ðə wʊmən ɑntu ðə dɛk. doʊmən wɑz ɹɪliv tə si, wən səm ə ðɛm ɹimuv ðɛɹ stʃɹeɪnʒ hɛlməts, ðət ðeɪ, ət list, wɝ mɛn; mɛn wɪð blæk aɪz, əɹ bɹaʊn, hu cʊɾə ɡɔn ənnoʊɾɪst ɪn tæntʃəkoʊ əɹ ɪljən. hi hæd bɪɡʌn tə hæv vɪʒənz ʌv ɑɹmiz ə blu-aɪd wɪmən wɪð sɔɹdz. ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪð sɔɹdz, hi θɔt, ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ðə si ɪɹʌptɪŋ.

The other soldiers followed the woman onto the deck. Domon was relieved to see, when some of them removed their strange helmets, that they, at least, were men; men with black eyes, or brown, who could have gone unnoticed in Tanchico or Illian. He had begun to have visions of armies of blue-eyed women with swords. Aes Sedai with swords, he thought, remembering the sea erupting.

ðə sintʃæn wʊmən sɝveɪd ðə ʃɪp ɛɹəɡənli, ðən pɪk doʊmən aʊɾ əz kæptən - ɪt hæd tə bi hɪm əɹ jɑɹən, baɪ ðɛɹ kloʊðz; ðə weɪ jɑɹən hæɾ ɪz aɪz kloʊzd ən wɑz mʌɾɝɪŋ pɹɛɹz ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ pɔɪntəd tə doʊmən - ən fɪkst ɪm wɪð ə stɛɹ laɪk ə spaɪk.

The Seanchan woman surveyed the ship arrogantly, then picked Domon out as captain - it had to be him or Yarin, by their clothes; the way Yarin had his eyes closed and was muttering prayers under his breath pointed to Domon - and fixed him with a stare like a spike.

"ɑɹ ðəɹ ɛni wɪmən əmʌŋ jəɹ kɹu əɹ pæsənʒɝz?" ʃi spoʊk wɪð ə sɑf slɝɪŋ ðət meɪɾ əɹ hɑɹd tə ʌndɝstænd, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ə snæp ɪn əɹ vɔɪs ðət sɛd ʃi wɑz juz tə ɡɛɾɪŋ ænsɝz. "spik ʌp, mæn, ɪf jə ɑɹ ðə kæptən. ɪf nɑt, weɪk ðəɾ ʌðɝ ful ən tɛl ɪm tə spik."

"Are there any women among your crew or passengers?" She spoke with a soft slurring that made her hard to understand, but there was a snap in her voice that said she was used to getting answers. "Speak up, man, if you are the captain. If not, wake that other fool and tell him to speak."

"aɪ də bi kæptən, maɪ leɪɾi," doʊmən sɛd kɔʃəsli. hi hæd noʊ aɪdiə haʊ tə ædʒɹɛs hɝ, ən i dɪd nɑt wɑnə pʊɾ ə fʊt ɹɔŋ. "aɪ hæv noʊ pæsənʒɝz, ən ðəɹ bi noʊ wɪmən ɪn maɪ kɹu." hi θɔɾ ə ðə ɡɝlz ən wɪmən u hæd bɪn kæɹiɾ ɔf, ænd, nɑt fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm, wʌndɝd wʌt ðiz foʊk wɑntəd wɪð ðɛm.

"I do be captain, my Lady," Domon said cautiously. He had no idea how to address her, and he did not want to put a foot wrong. "I have no passengers, and there be no women in my crew." He thought of the girls and women who had been carried off, and, not for the first time, wondered what these folk wanted with them.

ðə tu wɪmən dʒɹɛst əz wɪmən wɝ kʌmɪŋ ʌp fɹəm ðə lɔŋboʊt, wʌn dʒɹɔɪŋ ði ʌðɝ - doʊmən blɪŋkt - baɪ ə liʃ ə sɪlvɝi mɛɾəl əz ʃi klaɪmd əbɔɹd. ðə liʃ wɛn fɹəm ə bɹeɪslət wɔɹn baɪ ðə fɝst wʊmən tə ə kɑlɝ ɝaʊn ðə nɛk ə ðə sɛkənd. hi kəd nɑt tɛl wɛðɝ ɪt wɑz woʊvən əɹ dʒɔɪntəd - ɪt sim sʌmhaʊ tə bi boʊθ - bʌɾ ɪt wɑz klɪɹli ʌv ə pis wɪð boʊθ bɹeɪsləɾ ən kɑlɝ. ðə fɝst wʊmən ɡæðɝd ðə liʃ ɪn kɔɪlz əz ði ʌðɝ keɪm ɑntu ðə dɛk. ðə kɑlɝd wʊmən wɔɹ pleɪn dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ ən stʊd wɪð əɹ hænz foʊldəɾ ən əɹ aɪz ɑn ðə plæŋks ʌndɝ əɹ fit. ði ʌðɝ hæd ɹɛd pænəlz bɛɹɪŋ fɔɹkt, sɪlvɝ laɪtnɪŋ boʊls ɑn ðə bɹɛst ə hɝ blu dʒɹɛs ən ɑn ðə saɪdz ə hɝ skɝts, wɪtʃ ɛndəd ʃɔɹɾ ə ði æŋkəlz ə hɝ buts. doʊmən aɪd ðə wɪmən ənizəli.

The two women dressed as women were coming up from the longboat, one drawing the other - Domon blinked - by a leash of silvery metal as she climbed aboard. The leash went from a bracelet worn by the first woman to a collar around the neck of the second. He could not tell whether it was woven or jointed - it seemed somehow to be both - but it was clearly of a piece with both bracelet and collar. The first woman gathered the leash in coils as the other came onto the deck. The collared woman wore plain dark gray and stood with her hands folded and her eyes on the planks under her feet. The other had red panels bearing forked, silver lightning bolts on the breast of her blue dress and on the sides of her skirts, which ended short of the ankles of her boots. Domon eyed the women uneasily.

"spik sloʊli, mæn," ðə blu-aɪd wʊmən dɪmændəɾ ɪn əɹ slɝd spitʃ. ʃi keɪm əkɹɔs ðə dɛk tə kənfɹʌn hɪm, stɛɹɪŋ ʌp əɾ ɪm ən ɪn səm weɪ simɪŋ tɔlɝ ən lɑɹdʒɝ ðən hi. "ju ɑɹ ivən hɑɹɾɝ tə ʌndɝstæn ðən ðə ɹɛst ɪn ðɪs laɪt-fɔɹseɪkən lænd. ən aɪ meɪk noʊ kleɪm tə bi ʌv ðə blʌd. nɑt jɛt. æftɝ kɔɝɪn. . . . aɪm kæptən ɛdʒiənɪn."

"Speak slowly, man," the blue-eyed woman demanded in her slurred speech. She came across the deck to confront him, staring up at him and in some way seeming taller and larger than he. "You are even harder to understand than the rest in this Light-forsaken land. And I make no claim to be of the Blood. Not yet. After Corenne. . . . I am Captain Egeanin."

doʊmən ɹɪpiɾɪd hɪmsɛlf, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə spik sloʊli, ən æɾəd, "aɪ də bi ə pisfəl tʃɹeɪɾɝ, kæptən. aɪ min noʊ hɑɹm tə ju, ən aɪ hæv noʊ pɑɹɾ ɪn jəɹ wɔɹ." hi kəd nɑt hɛlp aɪɪŋ ðə tu wɪmən kənɛktəd baɪ ðə liʃ əɡɛn.

Domon repeated himself, trying to speak slowly, and added, "I do be a peaceful trader, Captain. I mean no harm to you, and I have no part in your war." He could not help eyeing the two women connected by the leash again.

"ə pisfəl tʃɹeɪɾɝ?" ɛdʒiənɪn mjuzd. "ɪn ðət keɪs, jəl bi fɹi tə ɡoʊ wʌns juv swɔɹn fiəlti əɡɛn." ʃi noʊɾəst ɪz ɡlænsɪz ən tɝn tə smaɪl ət ðə wɪmən wɪð ðə pɹaɪɾ ʌv oʊnɝʃɪp. "ju ædmaɪɹ maɪ deɪmeɪn? ʃi kɑs mi dɪɹ, bʌt ʃi wɑz wɝθ ɛvɹi kɔɪn. fju bʌt noʊbəlz oʊn ə deɪmeɪn, ən moʊst ɑɹ pɹɑpɝɾi ʌv ðə θɹoʊn. ʃiz stʃɹɔŋ, tʃɹeɪɾɝ. ʃi cʊɾə bɹoʊkən jəɹ ʃɪp tə splɪntɝz, hæɾ aɪ wɪʃt ɪt soʊ."

"A peaceful trader?" Egeanin mused. "In that case, you will be free to go once you have sworn fealty again." She noticed his glances and turned to smile at the women with the pride of ownership. "You admire my damane? She cost me dear, but she was worth every coin. Few but nobles own a damane, and most are property of the throne. She is strong, trader. She could have broken your ship to splinters, had I wished it so."

doʊmən stɛɹɾ ət ðə wɪmən ən ðə sɪlvɝ liʃ. hi hæd kənɛktəd ðə wʌn wɛɹɪŋ ðə laɪtnɪŋ wɪð ðə faɪɝi faʊntənz ɪn ðə si, ən əsumd ʃi wɑz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɛdʒiənɪn hæd dʒʌst sɛɾ ɪz hɛd wɝlɪŋ. noʊ wʌn kəd də ðət tə. . . . "ʃi ɪz ɛɛs sədaɪ?" hi sɛd dɪsbɪlivɪŋli.

Domon stared at the women and the silver leash. He had connected the one wearing the lightning with the fiery fountains in the sea, and assumed she was an Aes Sedai. Egeanin had just set his head whirling. No one could do that to. . . . "She is Aes Sedai?" he said disbelievingly.

hi nɛvɝ sɔ ðə kæʒəwəl bækhæn bloʊ kʌmɪŋ. hi stæɡɝɾ əz əɹ stil-bækt ɡɔnlət splɪɾ ɪz lɪp.

He never saw the casual backhand blow coming. He staggered as her steel-backed gauntlet split his lip.

"ðæt neɪm ɪz nɛvɝ spoʊkən," ɛdʒiənɪn sɛd wɪð ə deɪnʒɝəs sɔfnəs. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ oʊnli ðə deɪmeɪn, ðə liʃt wʌnz, ən naʊ ðeɪ sɝv ɪn tʃɹuθ əz wɛl əz neɪm." hɝ aɪz meɪɾ aɪs sim wɔɹm.

"That name is never spoken," Egeanin said with a dangerous softness. "There are only the damane, the Leashed Ones, and now they serve in truth as well as name." Her eyes made ice seem warm.

doʊmən swɑloʊd blʌɾ ən kɛpt ɪz hæn klɛntʃt əɾ ɪz saɪdz. ɪf i hæd hæɾ ə sɔɹd tə hænd, hi wəd nɑɾ əv lɛɾ ɪz kɹu tə slɔɾɝ əɡɛnst ə dʌzən ɑɹmɝd soʊlʒɝz, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ən ɛfɝt tə meɪk ɪz vɔɪs hʌmbəl. "aɪ mɛnt noʊ dɪsɹɪspɛkt, kæptən. aɪ noʊ nʌθɪŋ ə jə əɹ jəɹ weɪz. ɪf aɪ də əfɛnd, ɪts ɪɡnɝəns, noʊ ɪntɛntʃən."

Domon swallowed blood and kept his hand clenched at his sides. If he had had a sword to hand, he would not have led his crew to slaughter against a dozen armored soldiers, but it was an effort to make his voice humble. "I meant no disrespect, Captain. I know nothing of you or your ways. If I do offend, it is ignorance, no intention."

ʃi lʊkt ət hɪm, ðən sɛd, "ju ɑɹ ɔl ɪɡnɝənt, kæptən, bʌt jəl peɪ ðə dɛɾ ə jəɹ fɔɹfɑðɝz. ðɪs lænd wɑz aʊɝz, ən ɪɾəl bi aʊɝz əɡɛn. wɪð ðə ɹɪtɝn, ɪɾəl bi aʊɝz əɡɛn." doʊmən dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt tə seɪ - ʃʊɹli ʃi kən noʊ min ðət næɾɝɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ bi tʃɹu? - soʊ hi kɛpt ɪz maʊθ ʃʌt. "ju wɪl seɪl jəɹ vɛsəl tə fɑlm" - hi tʃɹaɪd tə pɹoʊtɛst, bʌɾ əɹ ɡlɛɹ saɪlənst ɪm - "wɛɹ jə ən jəɹ ʃɪp wɪl bi ɪɡzæmənd. ɪf jə ɑɹ noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə pisfəl tʃɹeɪɾɝ, əz jə kleɪm, jəl bi əlaʊd tə ɡoʊ jəɹ weɪ wən juv swɔɹn ði oʊðz."

She looked at him, then said, "You are all ignorant, Captain, but you will pay the debt of your forefathers. This land was ours, and it will be ours again. With the Return, it will be ours again." Domon did not know what to say - Surely she can no mean that nattering about Artur Hawkwing be true? - so he kept his mouth shut. "You will sail your vessel to Falme" - he tried to protest, but her glare silenced him - "where you and your ship will be examined. If you are no more than a peaceful trader, as you claim, you will be allowed to go your way when you have sworn the oaths."

"oʊðz, kæptən? wʌɾ oʊðz?"

"Oaths, Captain? What oaths?"

"tə oʊbeɪ, tə əweɪt, ən tə sɝv. jəɹ ænsɛstɝz ʃəɾ əv ɹɪmɛmbɝd."

"To obey, to await, and to serve. Your ancestors should have remembered."

ʃi ɡæðɝɾ əɹ pipəl - ɪksɛp fəɹ ə sɪŋɡəl mæn ɪn pleɪn ɑɹmɝ, wɪtʃ mɑɹkt ɪm ə loʊ ɹæŋk əz mʌtʃ əz ðə dɛpθ ə hɪz baʊ tə kæptən ɛdʒiənɪn - ən ðɛɹ lɔŋboʊt pʊld əweɪ təwɔɹd ðə lɑɹdʒɝ ʃɪp. ðə ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ sintʃæn ɡeɪv noʊ ɔɹɾɝz, oʊnli sæt kɹɔs-lɛɡəɾ ɑn ðə dɛk ən bɪɡæn ʃɑɹpənɪŋ ɪz sɔɹd waɪl ðə kɹu pʊt seɪl ɑn ən ɡɑɾ ʌndɝ weɪ. hi sim tə hæv noʊ fɪɹ ət biɪŋ əloʊn, ən doʊmən wəɾ əv pɝsənəli θɹoʊn oʊvɝbɔɹɾ ɛni kɹumən u ɹeɪzd ə hæn tə hɪm, fəɹ əz spɹeɪ meɪɾ əɹ weɪ əlɔŋ ðə koʊst, ðə sintʃæn ʃɪp fɑloʊd, aʊɾ ɪn dipɝ wɔɾɝ. ðəɹ wɑz ə maɪl bɪtwin ðə tu vɛsəlz, bʌt doʊmən nu ðəɹ wɑz noʊ hoʊp ʌv ɪskeɪp, ən i mɛn tə dɪlɪvɝ ðə mæn bæk tə kæptən ɛdʒiənɪn əz seɪfli əz ɪf i hæd bɪn kɹæɾəld ɪn ɪz mʌðɝz ɑɹmz.

She gathered her people - except for a single man in plain armor, which marked him of low rank as much as the depth of his bow to Captain Egeanin - and their longboat pulled away toward the larger ship. The remaining Seanchan gave no orders, only sat cross-legged on the deck and began sharpening his sword while the crew put sail on and got under way. He seemed to have no fear at being alone, and Domon would have personally thrown overboard any crewman who raised a hand to him, for as Spray made her way along the coast, the Seanchan ship followed, out in deeper water. There was a mile between the two vessels, but Domon knew there was no hope of escape, and he meant to deliver the man back to Captain Egeanin as safely as if he had been cradled in his mother's arms.

ɪt wɑz ə lɔŋ pæsədʒ tə fɑlm, ən doʊmən faɪnəli pɝsweɪɾəd ðə sintʃæn tə tɔk, ə lɪɾəl. ə dɑɹk-aɪd mæn ɪn ɪz mɪɾəl jɪɹz, wɪð ən oʊl skɑɹ əbʌv ɪz aɪz ən ənʌðɝ nɪkɪŋ ɪz tʃɪn, hɪz neɪm wɑz keɪbən, ən i hæd nʌθɪŋ bʌt kəntɛmp fəɹ ɛniwʌn ðɪs saɪɾ ə ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən. ðət ɡeɪv doʊmən ə moʊməns pɔz. meɪbi ðeɪ tʃɹuli də bi. . . . noʊ, ðət də bi mædnəs. keɪbənz spitʃ hæd ðə seɪm slɝ əz ɛdʒiənɪnz, bʌt wɛɹ hɝz wɑz sɪlk slaɪɾɪŋ əkɹɔs aɪɝn, hɪz wɑz lɛðɝ ɹæspɪŋ ɑn ɹɑk, ən moʊsli hi wɑntəd tə tɔk əbaʊt bæɾəlz, dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ, ən wɪmən i hæd noʊn. hæf ðə taɪm, doʊmən wɑz nɑt sɝɾən ɪf i wɝ spikɪŋ ə hɪɹ ən naʊ, əɹ ʌv wɛɹɛvɝ i hæd kʌm fɹʌm. ðə mæn wɑz sɝɾənli nɑt fɔɹθkʌmɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɛniθɪŋ doʊmən wɑntəd tə noʊ.

It was a long passage to Falme, and Domon finally persuaded the Seanchan to talk, a little. A dark-eyed man in his middle years, with an old scar above his eyes and another nicking his chin, his name was Caban, and he had nothing but contempt for anyone this side of the Aryth Ocean. That gave Domon a moment's pause. Maybe they truly do be. . . . No, that do be madness. Caban's speech had the same slur as Egeanin's, but where hers was silk sliding across iron, his was leather rasping on rock, and mostly he wanted to talk about battles, drinking, and women he had known. Half the time, Domon was not certain if he were speaking of here and now, or of wherever he had come from. The man was certainly not forthcoming about anything Domon wanted to know.

wʌns doʊmən æskt əbaʊt ðə deɪmeɪn. keɪbən ɹitʃt ʌp fɹəm wɛɹ i sæɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə hɛlmzmæn ən pʊt ðə pɔɪn ə hɪz sɔɹd tə doʊmənz θɹoʊt. "wɑtʃ wʌt jəɹ tʌŋ tʌtʃəz, əɹ jəl luz ɪt. ðæts ðə bɪznəs ə ðə blʌd, nɑt jəɹ kaɪnd. əɹ maɪn." hi ɡɹɪnd waɪl i sɛɾ ɪt, ən əz sun əz i wɑz dʌn, hi wɛn bæk tə slaɪɾɪŋ ə stoʊn əlɔŋ ɪz hɛvi, kɝv bleɪd.

Once Domon asked about the damane. Caban reached up from where he sat in front of the helmsman and put the point of his sword to Domon's throat. "Watch what your tongue touches, or you will lose it. That's the business of the Blood, not your kind. Or mine." He grinned while he said it, and as soon as he was done, he went back to sliding a stone along his heavy, curved blade.

doʊmən tʌtʃt ðə pɔɪn ə blʌd wɛlɪŋ əbʌv ɪz kɑlɝ ən ɹizɑlv nɑt tə æsk ðəɾ əɡɛn, ət list.

Domon touched the point of blood welling above his collar and resolved not to ask that again, at least.

ðə kloʊsɝ ðə tu vɛsəlz keɪm tə fɑlm, ðə mɔɹ ə ðə tɔl, skwɛɹ-lʊkɪŋ sintʃæn ʃɪps ðeɪ pæst, səm ʌndɝ seɪl, bʌt mɔɹ æŋkɝd. ɛvɹi wʌn wɑz blʌf-baʊɾ ən taʊɝd, əz bɪɡ əz ɛniθɪŋ doʊmən hæɾ ɛvɝ sin, ivən əmʌŋ ðə si foʊk. ə fju loʊkəl kɹæft, hi sɔ, wɪð ðɛɹ ʃɑɹp baʊz ən slæntəd seɪlz, dɑɹɾɪd əkɹɔs ðə ɡɹin swɛlz. ðə saɪt ɡeɪv ɪm kɑnfəɾəns ðəɾ ɛdʒiənɪn hæd spoʊkən ðə tʃɹuθ əbaʊt lɛɾɪŋ ɪm ɡoʊ fɹi.

The closer the two vessels came to Falme, the more of the tall, square-looking Seanchan ships they passed, some under sail, but more anchored. Every one was bluff-bowed and towered, as big as anything Domon had ever seen, even among the Sea Folk. A few local craft, he saw, with their sharp bows and slanted sails, darted across the green swells. The sight gave him confidence that Egeanin had spoken the truth about letting him go free.

wən spɹeɪ keɪm ʌp ɑn ðə hɛdlənd wɛɹ fɑlm stʊd, doʊmən ɡeɪpt ət ðə nʌmbɝz ə ðə sintʃæn ʃɪps æŋkɝɾ ɔf ðə hɑɹbɝ. hi tʃɹaɪd kaʊntɪŋ əm ən ɡeɪv ʌp əɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd, lɛs ðən hæfweɪ dʌn. hi hæd sin əz mɛni ʃɪps ɪn wʌn pleɪs bɪfɔɹ - ɪn ɪljən, ən tiɹ, ən ivən tæntʃəkoʊ - bʌt ðoʊz vɛsəlz hæɾ ɪnkluɾəd mɛni smɔlɝ kɹæft. mʌɾɝɪŋ ɡlʌmli tə hɪmsɛlf, hi tʊk spɹeɪ ɪndə ðə hɑɹbɝ, ʃɛpɝɾɪd baɪ hɝ ɡɹeɪt sintʃæn wɑtʃdɔɡ.

When Spray came up on the headland where Falme stood, Domon gaped at the numbers of the Seanchan ships anchored off the harbor. He tried counting them and gave up at a hundred, less than halfway done. He had seen as many ships in one place before - in Illian, and Tear, and even Tanchico - but those vessels had included many smaller craft. Muttering glumly to himself, he took Spray into the harbor, shepherded by her great Seanchan watchdog.

fɑlm stʊɾ ɑn ə spɪɾ ə læn ət ðə vɛɹi tɪp ə toʊmən hɛd, wɪð nʌθɪŋ fɝðɝ wɛst ʌv ɪɾ ɪksɛp ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən. haɪ klɪfs ɹæn tə ðə hɑɹbɝ maʊθ ɑn boʊθ saɪdz, ən ətɑp wʌn ə ðoʊz, wɛɹ ɛvɹi ʃɪp ɹʌnɪŋ ɪndə ðə hɑɹbɝ hæd tə pæs ʌndɝ ðɛm, stʊd ðə taʊɝz ə ðə wɑtʃɝz oʊvɝ ðə weɪvz. ə keɪdʒ hʌŋ oʊvɝ ðə saɪɾ ʌv wʌn ə ðə taʊɝz, wɪð ə mæn sɪɾɪŋ ɪn ɪt dɪspɑndənli, lɛɡz dæŋɡəlɪŋ θɹu ðə bɑɹz.

Falme stood on a spit of land at the very tip of Toman Head, with nothing further west of it except the Aryth Ocean. High cliffs ran to the harbor mouth on both sides, and atop one of those, where every ship running into the harbor had to pass under them, stood the towers of the Watchers Over the Waves. A cage hung over the side of one of the towers, with a man sitting in it despondently, legs dangling through the bars.

"hu ɪz ðæt?" doʊmən æskt.

"Who is that?" Domon asked.

keɪbən hæd faɪnəli ɡɪvən oʊvɝ ʃɑɹpənɪŋ ɪz sɔɹd, æftɝ doʊmən hæd bɪɡʌn tə wʌndɝ ɪf i mɛn tə ʃeɪv wɪð ɪt. ðə sintʃæn ɡlænst ʌp tə wɛɹ doʊmən pɔɪntəd. "oʊ. ðəɾ ɪz ðə fɝst wɑtʃɝ. nɑt ðə wʌn u sæɾ ɪn ðə tʃɛɹ wən wi fɝs keɪm, ʌv kɔɹs. ɛvɹi taɪm i daɪz, ðeɪ tʃuz ənʌðɝ, ən wi pʊɾ ɪm ɪn ðə keɪdʒ."

Caban had finally given over sharpening his sword, after Domon had begun to wonder if he meant to shave with it. The Seanchan glanced up to where Domon pointed. "Oh. That is the First Watcher. Not the one who sat in the chair when we first came, of course. Every time he dies, they choose another, and we put him in the cage."

"bʌt waɪ?" doʊmən dɪmændəd.

"But why?" Domon demanded.

keɪbənz ɡɹɪn ʃoʊd tu mɛni tiθ. "ðeɪ wɑtʃt fəɹ ðə ɹɔŋ θɪŋ, ən fɝɡɑt wən ðeɪ ʃʊɾə bɪn ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ."

Caban's grin showed too many teeth. "They watched for the wrong thing, and forgot when they should have been remembering."

doʊmən tɔɹ ɪz aɪz əweɪ fɹəm ðə sintʃæn. spɹeɪ slɪd daʊn ðə læst ɹil si swɛl ən ɪndə ðə kwaɪəɾɝ wɔɾɝz ə ðə hɑɹbɝ. aɪ də bi ə tʃɹeɪɾɝ, ən ɪts nʌn ə maɪ bɪznəs.
