Domon tore his eyes away from the Seanchan. Spray slid down the last real sea swell and into the quieter waters of the harbor. I do be a trader, and it is none of my business.

fɑlm ɹoʊz fɹəm stoʊn dɑks ʌp ðə sloʊps ə ðə hɑloʊ ðət meɪd ðə hɑɹbɝ. doʊmən kəd nɑt dɪsaɪd wɛðɝ ðə dɑɹk stoʊn haʊsəz meɪɾ ʌp ə ɡʊdli saɪz taʊn əɹ ə smɔl sɪɾi. sɝɾənli hi sɔ noʊ bɪldɪŋ ɪn ɪt tə ɹaɪvəl ðə smɔləs pæləs ɪn ɪljən.

Falme rose from stone docks up the slopes of the hollow that made the harbor. Domon could not decide whether the dark stone houses made up a goodly sized town or a small city. Certainly he saw no building in it to rival the smallest palace in Illian.

hi ɡaɪɾəd spɹeɪ tə ə pleɪs ət wʌn ə ðə dɑks, ən wʌndɝd, waɪl ðə kɹu taɪd ðə ʃɪp fæst, ɪf ðə sintʃæn maɪt baɪ səm ə ðə faɪɹwɝks ɪn ɪz hoʊld. nʌn ə maɪ bɪznəs.

He guided Spray to a place at one of the docks, and wondered, while the crew tied the ship fast, if the Seanchan might buy some of the fireworks in his hold. None of my business.

tə hɪz sɝpɹaɪz, ɛdʒiənɪn hæd hɝsɛlf ɹoʊd tə ðə dɑk wɪð əɹ deɪmeɪn. ðəɹ wɑz ənʌðɝ wʊmən wɛɹɪŋ ðə bɹeɪslət ðɪs taɪm, wɪð ðə ɹɛd pænəlz ən fɔɹk laɪtnɪŋ ɑn əɹ dʒɹɛs, bʌt ðə deɪmeɪn wɑz ðə seɪm sæd-feɪst wʊmən u nɛvɝ lʊkt ʌp ənlɛs ði ʌðɝ spoʊk tə hɝ. ɛdʒiənɪn hæd doʊmən ən ɪz kɹu hɝɾɪd ɔf ðə ʃɪp tə sɪɾ ɑn ðə dɑk ʌndɝ ði aɪz ʌv ə pɛɹ ə hɝ soʊlʒɝz - ʃi sim tə θɪŋk noʊ mɔɹ wɝ niɾəd, ən doʊmən wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə ɑɹɡju wɪð əɹ - waɪl ʌðɝz sɝtʃt spɹeɪ ʌndɝ əɹ dɝɛkʃən. ðə deɪmeɪn wɑz pɑɹɾ ə ðə sɝtʃ.

To his surprise, Egeanin had herself rowed to the dock with her damane. There was another woman wearing the bracelet this time, with the red panels and forked lightning on her dress, but the damane was the same sad-faced woman who never looked up unless the other spoke to her. Egeanin had Domon and his crew herded off the ship to sit on the dock under the eyes of a pair of her soldiers - she seemed to think no more were needed, and Domon was not about to argue with her - while others searched Spray under her direction. The damane was part of the search.

daʊn ðə dɑk, ə θɪŋ əpɪɹd. doʊmən kəd θɪŋk ə noʊ ʌðɝ weɪ tə dɪskɹaɪb ɪt. ə hʌlkɪŋ kɹitʃɝ wɪð ə lɛðɝi, ɡɹeɪ-ɡɹin haɪɾ ən ə bik ʌv ə maʊθ ɪn ə wɛdʒ-ʃeɪp hɛd. ən θɹi aɪz. ɪt lʌmbɝɾ əlɔŋ bɪsaɪɾ ə mæn huz ɑɹmɝ bɔɹ θɹi peɪntəɾ aɪz, dʒʌs laɪk ðoʊz ə ðə kɹitʃɝ. ðə loʊkəl pipəl, dɑkmən ən seɪlɝz ɪn ɹʌfli ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ʃɝts ən lɔŋ vɛsts tə ðɛɹ niz, ʃaɪɾ əweɪ əz ðə pɛɹ pæst, bʌt noʊ sintʃæn ɡeɪv əm ə sɛkənd ɡlæns. ðə mæn wɪð ðə bist sim tə bi dɝɛktɪŋ ɪt wɪð hæn sɪɡnəlz.

Down the dock, a thing appeared. Domon could think of no other way to describe it. A hulking creature with a leathery, gray-green hide and a beak of a mouth in a wedge-shaped head. And three eyes. It lumbered along beside a man whose armor bore three painted eyes, just like those of the creature. The local people, dockmen and sailors in roughly embroidered shirts and long vests to their knees, shied away as the pair passed, but no Seanchan gave them a second glance. The man with the beast seemed to be directing it with hand signals.

mæn ən kɹitʃɝ tɝn ɪn əmʌŋ ðə bɪldɪŋz, livɪŋ doʊmən stɛɹɪŋ ən ɪz kɹu mʌɾɝɪŋ tə ðɛmsɛlvz. ðə tu sintʃæn ɡɑɹdz snɪɹɾ əɾ əm saɪlənli. noʊ maɪ bɪznəs, doʊmən ɹimaɪndəd hɪmsɛlf. hɪz bɪznəs wɑz ɪz ʃɪp.

Man and creature turned in among the buildings, leaving Domon staring and his crew muttering to themselves. The two Seanchan guards sneered at them silently. No my business, Domon reminded himself. His business was his ship.

ði ɛɹ hæɾ ə fəmɪljɝ smɛl ə sɔlt wɔɾɝ ən pɪtʃ. hi ʃɪftəɾ ənizəli ɑn ðə stoʊn, hɑt fɹəm ðə sʌn, ən wʌndɝd wʌt ðə sintʃæn wɝ sɝtʃɪŋ fɔɹ. wʌt ðə deɪmeɪn wɑz sɝtʃɪŋ fɔɹ. wʌndɝd wʌt ðət θɪŋ hæd bɪn. ɡʌlz kɹaɪd, wilɪŋ əbʌv ðə hɑɹbɝ. hi θɔɾ ə ðə saʊnz ə keɪdʒ mæn maɪt meɪk. ɪts noʊ maɪ bɪznəs.

The air had a familiar smell of salt water and pitch. He shifted uneasily on the stone, hot from the sun, and wondered what the Seanchan were searching for. What the damane was searching for. Wondered what that thing had been. Gulls cried, wheeling above the harbor. He thought of the sounds a caged man might make. It is no my business.

ɪvɛntʃəwəli ɛdʒiənɪn lɛd ði ʌðɝz bæk ɑntu ðə dɑk. ðə sintʃæn kæptən hæd sʌmθɪŋ ɹæpt ɪn ə pis ə jɛloʊ sɪlk, doʊmən noʊɾəd wɛɹəli. sʌmθɪŋ smɔl ɪnʌf tə kæɹi ɪn wʌn hænd, bʌt wɪtʃ ʃi hɛl kɛɹfəli ɪn boʊθ.

Eventually Egeanin led the others back onto the dock. The Seanchan captain had something wrapped in a piece of yellow silk, Domon noted warily. Something small enough to carry in one hand, but which she held carefully in both.

hi ɡɑt tə hɪz fit - sloʊli, fəɹ ðə soʊlʒɝz' seɪk, ðoʊ ðɛɹ aɪz hɛl ðə seɪm kəntɛmp keɪbənz dɪd. "ju si, kæptən? aɪ də bi oʊnli ə pisfəl tʃɹeɪɾɝ. pɝhæps jəɹ pipəl wəd kɛɹ tə baɪ səm faɪɹwɝks?"

He got to his feet - slowly, for the soldiers' sake, though their eyes held the same contempt Caban's did. "You see, Captain? I do be only a peaceful trader. Perhaps your people would care to buy some fireworks?"

"pɝhæps, tʃɹeɪɾɝ." ðəɹ wɑz ən ɛɹ ə səpɹɛst ɪksaɪtmən əbaʊɾ əɹ ðət meɪɾ ɪm ənizi, ən əɹ nɛkst wɝdz ɪnkɹis ðə filɪŋ. "ju wɪl kʌm wɪð mi."

"Perhaps, trader." There was an air of suppressed excitement about her that made him uneasy, and her next words increased the feeling. "You will come with me."

ʃi toʊl tu soʊlʒɝz tə kʌm əlɔŋ, ən wʌn ə ðɛm ɡeɪv doʊmən ə pʊʃ tə ɡɛɾ ɪm stɑɹɾəd. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə ɹʌf ʃʌv; doʊmən hæd sin fɑɹmɝz pʊʃ ə kaʊ ɪn ðə seɪm weɪ tə meɪk ɪt muv. sɛɾɪŋ ɪz tiθ, hi fɑloʊɾ ɛdʒiənɪn.

She told two soldiers to come along, and one of them gave Domon a push to get him started. It was not a rough shove; Domon had seen farmers push a cow in the same way to make it move. Setting his teeth, he followed Egeanin.

ðə kɑbəlstoʊn stʃɹit klaɪm ðə sloʊp, livɪŋ ðə smɛl ə ðə hɑɹbɝ bɪhaɪnd. ðə sleɪt-ɹuf haʊsəz ɡɹu lɑɹdʒɝ ən tɔlɝ əz ðə stʃɹit klaɪmd. sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli fəɹ ə taʊn hɛl baɪ ɪnveɪɾɝz, ðə stʃɹits hɛl mɔɹ loʊkəl pipəl ðən sintʃæn soʊlʒɝz, ən naʊ ən əɡɛn ə kɝteɪn pɑlɑnkwɪn wɑz bɔɹn pæs baɪ bɛɹ-tʃɛstəd mɛn. ðə fɑlmɛn sim tə bi ɡoʊɪŋ əbaʊt ðɛɹ bɪznəs əz ɪf ðə sintʃæn wɝ nɑt ðɛɹ. əɹ ɔlmoʊs nɑt ðɛɹ. wən pɑlɑnkwɪn əɹ soʊlʒɝ pæst, boʊθ pʊɹ foʊk, wɪð oʊnli ə kɝlɪŋ laɪn əɹ tu wɝkt ɑn ðɛɹ dɝɾi kloʊðz, ən ðə ɹɪtʃɝ, wɪð ʃɝts, vɛsts, ən dʒɹɛsəz kʌvɝd fɹəm ʃoʊldɝ tə weɪst ɪn ɪntʃɹəkətli ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd pæɾɝnz, baʊɾ ən ɹɪmeɪn bɛn əntɪl ðə sintʃæn wɝ ɡɔn. ðeɪ dɪd ðə seɪm fəɹ doʊmən ən ɪz ɡɑɹd. niðɝ ɛdʒiənɪn nɔɹ əɹ soʊlʒɝz soʊ mʌtʃ əz ɡlænst ət ðɛm.

The cobblestone street climbed the slope, leaving the smell of the harbor behind. The slate-roofed houses grew larger and taller as the street climbed. Surprisingly for a town held by invaders, the streets held more local people than Seanchan soldiers, and now and again a curtained palanquin was borne past by bare-chested men. The Falmen seemed to be going about their business as if the Seanchan were not there. Or almost not there. When palanquin or soldier passed, both poor folk, with only a curling line or two worked on their dirty clothes, and the richer, with shirts, vests, and dresses covered from shoulder to waist in intricately embroidered patterns, bowed and remained bent until the Seanchan were gone. They did the same for Domon and his guard. Neither Egeanin nor her soldiers so much as glanced at them.

doʊmən ɹilaɪzd wɪð ə sʌɾən ʃɑk ðət səm ə ðə loʊkəl pipəl ðeɪ pæst wɔɹ dæɡɝz ət ðɛɹ bɛls, ən ɪn ə fju keɪsəz sɔɹdz. hi wɑz soʊ sɝpɹaɪz ðəɾ i spoʊk wɪθaʊt θɪŋkɪŋ. "sʌm ə ðɛm bi ɑn jəɹ saɪd?"

Domon realized with a sudden shock that some of the local people they passed wore daggers at their belts, and in a few cases swords. He was so surprised that he spoke without thinking. "Some of them be on your side?"

ɛdʒiənɪn fɹaʊn oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ ət hɪm, ɑbviəsli pʌzəld. wɪθaʊt sloʊɪŋ, ʃi lʊkt ət ðə pipəl ən nɑɾəd tə hɝsɛlf. "ju min ðə sɔɹdz. ðeɪ ɑɹ əɹ pipəl, naʊ, tʃɹeɪɾɝ; ðeɪv swɔɹn ði oʊðz." ʃi stɑpt əbɹʌpli, pɔɪntɪŋ əɾ ə tɔl, hɛvi-ʃoʊldɝd mæn wɪð ə hɛvəli ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd vɛst ən ə sɔɹd swɪŋɪŋ ɑn ə pleɪn lɛðɝ bælʒɹɪk. "ju."

Egeanin frowned over her shoulder at him, obviously puzzled. Without slowing, she looked at the people and nodded to herself. "You mean the swords. They are our people, now, trader; they have sworn the oaths." She stopped abruptly, pointing at a tall, heavy-shouldered man with a heavily embroidered vest and a sword swinging on a plain leather baldric. "You."

ðə mæn hɔltəɾ ɪn mɪd-stɛp, wʌn fʊɾ ɪn ði ɛɹ ən ə fɹaɪɾənd lʊk sʌɾənli ɑn ɪz feɪs. ɪt wɑz ə hɑɹd feɪs, bʌɾ i lʊkt əz ɪf i wɑntəd tə ɹʌn. ɪnstɛd, hi tɝn tə hɝ ən baʊd, hænz ɑn niz, aɪz fɪkst ɑn əɹ buts. "haʊ meɪ ðɪs wʌn sɝv ðə kæptən?" hi æskt ɪn ə taɪt vɔɪs.

The man halted in mid-step, one foot in the air and a frightened look suddenly on his face. It was a hard face, but he looked as if he wanted to run. Instead, he turned to her and bowed, hands on knees, eyes fixed on her boots. "How may this one serve the captain?" he asked in a tight voice.

"ju ɑɹ ə mɝtʃənt?" ɛdʒiənɪn sɛd. "ju hæv swɔɹn ði oʊðz?"

"You are a merchant?" Egeanin said. "You have sworn the oaths?"

"jɛs, kæptən. jɛs." hi dɪd nɑt teɪk ɪz aɪz fɹəm əɹ fit.

"Yes, Captain. Yes." He did not take his eyes from her feet.

"wʌt dʒju tɛl ðə pipəl wən jə teɪk jəɹ wæɡənz ɪnlænd?"

"What do you tell the people when you take your wagons inland?"

"ðæt ðeɪ mʌst oʊbeɪ ðə fɔɹʌnɝz, kæptən, əweɪt ðə ɹɪtɝn, ən sɝv ðoʊz u kʌm hoʊm."

"That they must obey the Forerunners, Captain, await the Return, and serve Those Who Come Home."

"æn dʒju nɛvɝ θɪŋk tə juz ðət sɔɹɾ əɡɛnst ʌs?"

"And do you never think to use that sword against us?"

ðə mænz hænz wɛnt waɪt-nʌkəld ɡɹɪpɪŋ ɪz niz, ən ðəɹ wɑz sʌɾənli swɛɾ ɪn ɪz vɔɪs. "aɪ hæv swɔɹn ði oʊðz, kæptən. aɪ oʊbeɪ, əweɪt, ən sɝv."

The man's hands went white-knuckled gripping his knees, and there was suddenly sweat in his voice. "I have sworn the oaths, Captain. I obey, await, and serve."

"ju si?" ɛdʒiənɪn sɛd, tɝnɪŋ tə doʊmən. "ðɛɹ ɪz noʊ ɹizən tə fɝbɪɾ əm wɛpənz. ðəɹ mʌs bi tʃɹeɪd, ən mɝtʃəns mʌs pɹətɛk ðɛmsɛlvz fɹəm bændəts. wi əlaʊ ðə pipəl tə kʌm ən ɡoʊ əz ðeɪ wɪl, soʊ lɔŋ əz ðeɪ oʊbeɪ, əweɪt, ən sɝv. ðɛɹ fɔɹfɑðɝz bɹoʊk ðɛɹ oʊðz, bʌt ðiz əv lɝn bɛɾɝ." ʃi stɑɹɾəd bæk ʌp ðə hɪl, ən ðə soʊlʒɝz pʊʃt doʊmən æftɝ hɝ.

"You see?" Egeanin said, turning to Domon. "There is no reason to forbid them weapons. There must be trade, and merchants must protect themselves from bandits. We allow the people to come and go as they will, so long as they obey, await, and serve. Their forefathers broke their oaths, but these have learned better." She started back up the hill, and the soldiers pushed Domon after her.

hi lʊk bæk ət ðə mɝtʃənt. ðə mæn steɪd bɛn əz i wɑz tɪl ɛdʒiənɪn wɑz tɛn peɪsɪz ʌp ðə stʃɹit, ðən i stʃɹeɪɾənd ən hɝid ði ʌðɝ weɪ, lipɪŋ daʊn ðə sloʊpɪŋ stʃɹit.

He looked back at the merchant. The man stayed bent as he was till Egeanin was ten paces up the street, then he straightened and hurried the other way, leaping down the sloping street.

ɛdʒiənɪn ən ɪz ɡɑɹdz dɪd nɑt lʊk ɝaʊnd, iðɝ, wən ə maʊntəd sintʃæn tʃɹup pæs ðɛm, klaɪmɪŋ ðə stʃɹit. ðə soʊlʒɝz ɹoʊd kɹitʃɝz ðət lʊkt ɔlmoʊs laɪk kæts ðə saɪz ə hɔɹsəz, bʌt wɪð lɪzɝdz' skeɪlz ɹɪpəlɪŋ bɹɑnz bɪniθ ðɛɹ sæɾəlz. klɔd fit ɡɹæsp ðə kɑbəlstoʊnz. ə θɹi-aɪd hɛd tɝn tə ɹəɡɑɹd doʊmən əz ðə tʃɹup klaɪm baɪ; əsaɪd fɹəm ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls, ɪt sim tu - noʊɪŋ - fəɹ doʊmənz pis ə maɪnd. hi stʌmbəld ən ɔlmoʊs fɛl. ɔl əlɔŋ ðə stʃɹit, ðə fɑlmɛn wɝ pɹɛsɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz bæk əɡɛns ðə fɹʌns ə ðə bɪldɪŋz, səm kloʊzɪŋ ðɛɹ aɪz. ðə sintʃæn peɪɾ əm noʊ hid.

Egeanin and his guards did not look around, either, when a mounted Seanchan troop passed them, climbing the street. The soldiers rode creatures that looked almost like cats the size of horses, but with lizards' scales rippling bronze beneath their saddles. Clawed feet grasped the cobblestones. A three-eyed head turned to regard Domon as the troop climbed by; aside from everything else, it seemed too - knowing - for Domon's peace of mind. He stumbled and almost fell. All along the street, the Falmen were pressing themselves back against the fronts of the buildings, some closing their eyes. The Seanchan paid them no heed.

doʊmən ʌndɝstʊd waɪ ðə sintʃæn kəɾ əlaʊ ðə pipəl əz mʌtʃ fɹiɾəm əz ðeɪ dɪd. hi wʌndɝɾ ɪf i wʊɾə hæd nɝv ɪnʌf tə ɹɪzɪst. deɪmeɪn. mɑnstɝz. hi wʌndɝɾ ɪf ðəɹ wɑz ɛniθɪŋ tə stɑp ðə sintʃæn fɹəm mɑɹtʃɪŋ ɔl ðə weɪ tə ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝld. noʊ maɪ bɪznəs, hi ɹimaɪndəd hɪmsɛlf ɹʌfli, ən kənsɪɾɝd wɛðɝ ðəɹ wɑz ɛni weɪ tə əvɔɪd ðə sintʃæn ɪn ɪz fjutʃɝ tʃɹeɪɾɪŋ.

Domon understood why the Seanchan could allow the people as much freedom as they did. He wondered if he would have had nerve enough to resist. Damane. Monsters. He wondered if there was anything to stop the Seanchan from marching all the way to the Spine of the World. No my business, he reminded himself roughly, and considered whether there was any way to avoid the Seanchan in his future trading.

ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə tɑp ə ði ɪnklaɪn, wɛɹ ðə taʊn ɡeɪv weɪ tə hɪlz. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ taʊn wɔl. əhɛd wɝ ði ɪnz ðət sɝv mɝtʃəns u tʃɹeɪɾɪd ɪnlænd, ən wæɡən jɑɹdz ən steɪbəlz. hɪɹ, ðə haʊsəz wʊɾə meɪd ɹɪspɛktəbəl mænɝz fəɹ ðə maɪnɝ lɔɹdz ɪn ɪljən. ðə lɑɹdʒəst ə ðɛm hæɾ ən ɑnɝ ɡɑɹɾ ə sintʃæn soʊlʒɝz aʊt fɹʌnt, ən ə blu-ɛdʒ bænɝ bɛɹɪŋ ə ɡoʊldən, spɹɛd-wɪŋ hɔk ɹɪpəlɪŋ əbʌv ɪt. ɛdʒiənɪn sɝɛndɝɾ əɹ sɔɹɾ ən dæɡɝ bɪfɔɹ teɪkɪŋ doʊmən ɪnsaɪd. hɝ tu soʊlʒɝz ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ðə stʃɹit. doʊmən bɪɡæn tə swɛt. hi smɛld ə lɔɹɾ ɪn ðɪs; ɪt wɑz nɛvɝ ɡʊd tə də bɪznəs wɪð ə lɔɹɾ ɑn ðə lɔɹdz oʊn ɡɹaʊnd.

They reached the top of the incline, where the town gave way to hills. There was no town wall. Ahead were the inns that served merchants who traded inland, and wagon yards and stables. Here, the houses would have made respectable manors for the minor lords in Illian. The largest of them had an honor guard of Seanchan soldiers out front, and a blue-edged banner bearing a golden, spread-winged hawk rippling above it. Egeanin surrendered her sword and dagger before taking Domon inside. Her two soldiers remained in the street. Domon began to sweat. He smelled a lord in this; it was never good to do business with a lord on the lord's own ground.

ɪn ðə fɹʌn hɔl ɛdʒiənɪn lɛf doʊmən ət ðə dɔɹ ən spoʊk tə ə sɝvənt. ə loʊkəl mæn, dʒʌdʒɪŋ baɪ ðə fʊl slivz ə hɪz ʃɝɾ ən ðə spaɪɹəlz ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd əkɹɔs ɪz tʃɛst; doʊmən bɪlivd i kɑt ðə wɝdz "haɪ lɔɹd." ðə sɝvən hɝiɾ əweɪ, ɹɪtɝnɪŋ faɪnəli tə liɾ əm tə wʌt wɑz ʃʊɹli ðə lɑɹdʒəst ɹum ɪn ðə haʊs. ɛvɹi stɪk ə fɝnɪtʃɝ hæd bɪn klɪɹɾ aʊɾ ʌv ɪt, ivən ðə ɹʌɡz, ən ðə stoʊn flɔɹ wɑz pɑlɪʃt tə ə bɹaɪt ɡlim. foʊldɪŋ skɹinz peɪntəd wɪð stʃɹeɪnʒ bɝdz hɪd wɔlz ən wɪndoʊz.

In the front hall Egeanin left Domon at the door and spoke to a servant. A local man, judging by the full sleeves of his shirt and the spirals embroidered across his chest; Domon believed he caught the words "High Lord." The servant hurried away, returning finally to lead them to what was surely the largest room in the house. Every stick of furniture had been cleared out of it, even the rugs, and the stone floor was polished to a bright gleam. Folding screens painted with strange birds hid walls and windows.

ɛdʒiənɪn stɑp dʒʌst ɪnsaɪd ðə ɹum. wən doʊmən tʃɹaɪd tə æsk wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ ən waɪ, ʃi saɪlənst ɪm wɪð ə sævədʒ ɡlɛɹ ən ə wɝdləs ɡɹaʊl. ʃi dɪd nɑt muv, bʌt ʃi simd ɑn ðə pɔɪn ə baʊnsɪŋ ɑn əɹ toʊz. ʃi hɛld wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɑz ʃi hæd teɪkən fɹəm ɪz ʃɪp əz ɪf ɪt wɝ pɹɛʃəs. hi tʃɹaɪd tə ɪmædʒən wʌɾ ɪt kəd bi.

Egeanin stopped just inside the room. When Domon tried to ask where they were and why, she silenced him with a savage glare and a wordless growl. She did not move, but she seemed on the point of bouncing on her toes. She held whatever it was she had taken from his ship as if it were precious. He tried to imagine what it could be.

sʌɾənli ə ɡɔŋ saʊndəd sɔfli, ən ðə sintʃæn wʊmən dʒɹɑp tə hɝ niz, sɛɾɪŋ ðə sɪlk-ɹæp sʌmθɪŋ kɛɹfəli bɪsaɪd hɝ. əɾ ə lʊk fɹəm hɝ, doʊmən ɡɑt daʊn əz wɛl. lɔɹdz hæd stʃɹeɪnʒ weɪz, ən i səspɛktəd sintʃæn lɔɹdz maɪɾ əv stʃɹeɪnʒɝ wʌnz ðən i nu.

Suddenly a gong sounded softly, and the Seanchan woman dropped to her knees, setting the silk-wrapped something carefully beside her. At a look from her, Domon got down as well. Lords had strange ways, and he suspected Seanchan lords might have stranger ones than he knew.

tu mɛn əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ ət ðə fɑɹ ɛn ə ðə ɹum. wʌn hæd ðə lɛf saɪɾ ə hɪz skælp ʃeɪvd, hɪz ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ peɪl ɡoʊldən hɛɹ bɹeɪɾɪd ən hæŋɪŋ daʊn oʊvɝ ɪz ɪɹ tə hɪz ʃoʊldɝ. hɪz dip jɛloʊ ɹoʊb wɑz dʒʌs lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə lɛt ðə toʊz ə jɛloʊ slɪpɝz pik aʊt wən i wɔkt. ði ʌðɝ wɔɹ ə blu sɪlk ɹoʊb, bɹoʊkeɪɾɪd wɪð bɝdz ən lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə tʃɹeɪl nɪɹli ə spæn ɑn ðə flɔɹ bɪhaɪn hɪm. hɪz hɛd wɑz ʃeɪv bɔld, ən ɪz fɪŋɡɝneɪlz wɝ ət list ən ɪntʃ lɔŋ, ðoʊz ɑn ðə fɝs tu fɪŋɡɝz ʌv itʃ hæn lækɝd blu. doʊmənz maʊθ dʒɹɑpt oʊpən.

Two men appeared in the doorway at the far end of the room. One had the left side of his scalp shaved, his remaining pale golden hair braided and hanging down over his ear to his shoulder. His deep yellow robe was just long enough to let the toes of yellow slippers peek out when he walked. The other wore a blue silk robe, brocaded with birds and long enough to trail nearly a span on the floor behind him. His head was shaved bald, and his fingernails were at least an inch long, those on the first two fingers of each hand lacquered blue. Domon's mouth dropped open.

"ju ɑɹ ɪn ðə pɹɛzəns ə ðə haɪ lɔɹd tʃɹɑk," ðə jɛloʊ-hɛɹd mæn ɪntoʊnd, "hu lidz ðoʊz u kʌm bɪfɔɹ, ən səkɹz ðə ɹɪtɝn."

"You are in the presence of the High Lord Turak," the yellow-haired man intoned, "who leads Those Who Come Before, and succors the Return."

ɛdʒiənɪn pɹɑstʃɹeɪɾɪd hɝsɛlf wɪð əɹ hænz əɾ əɹ saɪdz. doʊmən ɪməteɪɾɪd əɹ wɪð əlækɹəɾi. ivən ðə haɪ lɔɹdz ə tiɹ wəd noʊ dɪmæn ðɪs, hi θɔt. aʊɾ ə ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz aɪ, hi sɔ ɛdʒiənɪn kɪsɪŋ ðə flɔɹ. wɪð ə ɡɹɪmɑs, hi dɪsaɪɾɪd ðəɹ wɑz ə lɪmət tə ɪməteɪʃən. ðeɪ kən noʊ si wɛðɝ aɪ də əɹ noʊ ɛniweɪ.

Egeanin prostrated herself with her hands at her sides. Domon imitated her with alacrity. Even the High Lords of Tear would no demand this, he thought. Out of the corner of his eye, he saw Egeanin kissing the floor. With a grimace, he decided there was a limit to imitation. They can no see whether I do or no anyway.

ɛdʒiənɪn sʌɾənli stʊd. hi stɑɹɾəd tə ɹaɪz əz wɛl, ən meɪɾ ɪɾ əz fɑɹ əz wʌn ni bɪfɔɹ ə ɡɹaʊl ɪn əɹ θɹoʊɾ ən ə skændəlaɪz lʊk ɑn ðə feɪs ə ðə mæn wɪð ðə bɹeɪd pʊɾ ɪm bæk daʊn, feɪs tə ðə flɔɹ ən mʌɾɝɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ. aɪ wəd noʊ də ðɪs fəɹ ðə kɪŋ ʌv ɪljən ən ðə kaʊnsəl ə naɪn təɡɛðɝ.

Egeanin suddenly stood. He started to rise as well, and made it as far as one knee before a growl in her throat and a scandalized look on the face of the man with the braid put him back down, face to the floor and muttering under his breath. I would no do this for the King of Illian and the Council of Nine together.

"jɔɹ neɪm ɪz ɛdʒiənɪn?" ɪt hæd tə bi ðə vɔɪs ə ðə mæn ɪn ðə blu ɹoʊb. hɪz slɝɪŋ spitʃ hæɾ ə ɹɪðəm ɔlmoʊs laɪk sɪŋɪŋ.

"Your name is Egeanin?" It had to be the voice of the man in the blue robe. His slurring speech had a rhythm almost like singing.

"aɪ wɑz soʊ neɪmd ɑn maɪ sɔɹd-deɪ, haɪ lɔɹd," ʃi ɹɪplaɪd hʌmbli.

"I was so named on my sword-day, High Lord," she replied humbly.

"ðɪs ɪz ə faɪn spɛsəmən, ɛdʒiənɪn. kwaɪt ɹɛɹ. dʒju wɪʃ ə peɪmənt?"

"This is a fine specimen, Egeanin. Quite rare. Do you wish a payment?"

"ðæt ðə haɪ lɔɹɾ ɪz plizd ɪz peɪmən ɪnʌf. aɪ lɪv tə sɝv, haɪ lɔɹd."

"That the High Lord is pleased is payment enough. I live to serve, High Lord."

"aɪ wɪl mɛnʃən jəɹ neɪm tə ði ɛmpɹɛs, ɛdʒiənɪn. æftɝ ðə ɹɪtɝn, nu neɪmz wɪl bi kɔl tə ðə blʌd. ʃoʊ jɝsɛlf fɪt, ən jə meɪ ʃɛd ðə neɪm ɛdʒiənɪn fəɹ ə haɪɝ."

"I will mention your name to the Empress, Egeanin. After the Return, new names will be called to the Blood. Show yourself fit, and you may shed the name Egeanin for a higher."

"ðə haɪ lɔɹɾ ɑnɝz mi."

"The High Lord honors me."

"jɛs. jə meɪ liv mi."

"Yes. You may leave me."

doʊmən kəd si nʌθɪŋ bʌɾ əɹ buts bækɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə ɹum, pɔzɪŋ əɾ ɪntɝvəlz fəɹ baʊz. ðə dɔɹ kloʊz bɪhaɪn hɝ. ðəɹ wɑz ə lɔŋ saɪləns. hi wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ swɛt fɹəm ɪz fɔɹhɛd dʒɹɪp ɑntu ðə flɔɹ wən tʃɹɑk spoʊk əɡɛn.

Domon could see nothing but her boots backing out of the room, pausing at intervals for bows. The door closed behind her. There was a long silence. He was watching sweat from his forehead drip onto the floor when Turak spoke again.

"ju meɪ ɹaɪz, tʃɹeɪɾɝ."

"You may rise, trader."

doʊmən ɡɑt tə hɪz fit, ən sɔ wʌt tʃɹɑk hɛld ɪn ɪz lɔŋ-neɪl fɪŋɡɝz. ðə kwəndɪlɝ dɪsk ʃeɪpt ɪndə ði eɪntʃən sil ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ɛdʒiənɪnz ɹiækʃən wən i mɛnʃən ɛɛs sədaɪ, doʊmən bɪɡæn tə swɛɾ ɪn ɝnɪst. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ænəmɑsəɾi ɪn ðə haɪ lɔɹdz dɑɹk aɪz, oʊnli ə slaɪt kjʊɹiɑsəɾi, bʌt doʊmən dɪd nɑt tʃɹʌs lɔɹdz.

Domon got to his feet, and saw what Turak held in his long-nailed fingers. The cuendillar disk shaped into the ancient seal of the Aes Sedai. Remembering Egeanin's reaction when he mentioned Aes Sedai, Domon began to sweat in earnest. There was no animosity in the High Lord's dark eyes, only a slight curiosity, but Domon did not trust lords.

"du jə noʊ wʌt ðɪs ɪz, tʃɹeɪɾɝ?"

"Do you know what this is, trader?"

"noʊ, haɪ lɔɹd." doʊmənz ɹɪplaɪ wɑz əz stɛɾi əz ə ɹɑk; noʊ tʃɹeɪɾɝ læstəd lɔŋ u kəd nɑt laɪ wɪð ə stʃɹeɪt feɪs ən ən izi vɔɪs.

"No, High Lord." Domon's reply was as steady as a rock; no trader lasted long who could not lie with a straight face and an easy voice.

"æn jɛt jə kɛpt ɪɾ ɪn ə sikɹət pleɪs."

"And yet you kept it in a secret place."

"aɪ də kəlɛkt oʊl θɪŋz, haɪ lɔɹd, fɹəm taɪmz pæst. ðəɹ də bi ðoʊz u wəd stil sʌtʃ, dɪd ðeɪ leɪ izi tə hænd."

"I do collect old things, High Lord, from times past. There do be those who would steal such, did they lay easy to hand."

tʃɹɑk ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ðə blæk-ænd-waɪt dɪsk fəɹ ə moʊmənt. "ðɪs ɪz kwəndɪlɝ, tʃɹeɪɾɝ - dʒju noʊ ðət neɪm? - ən oʊldɝ ðən jə pɝhæps noʊ. kʌm wɪð mi."

Turak regarded the black-and-white disk for a moment. "This is cuendillar, trader - do you know that name? - and older than you perhaps know. Come with me."

doʊmən fɑloʊd ðə mæn kɔʃəsli, filɪŋ ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ ʃʊɹ ə hɪmsɛlf. wɪð ɛni lɔɹɾ ə ðə lænz i nu, ɪf ɡɑɹdz wɝ gɑnə bi sʌmənd, ðeɪ ɔlɹɛɾi wəɾ əv bɪn. bʌt ðə lɪɾəl i hæd sin ə sintʃæn toʊld ɪm ðeɪ dɪd nɑt də θɪŋz əz ʌðɝ mɛn dɪd. hi skuld ɪz feɪs tə stɪlnəs.

Domon followed the man cautiously, feeling a little more sure of himself. With any lord of the lands he knew, if guards were going to be summoned, they already would have been. But the little he had seen of Seanchan told him they did not do things as other men did. He schooled his face to stillness.

hi wɑz lɛɾ ɪndə ənʌðɝ ɹum. hi θɔt ðə fɝnɪtʃɝ hɪɹ hæd tə hæv bɪn bɹɔt baɪ tʃɹɑk. ɪt sim tə bi meɪɾ ə kɝvz, wɪð noʊ stʃɹeɪt laɪnz əɾ ɔl, ən ðə wʊd wɑz pɑlɪʃt tə bɹɪŋ aʊt stʃɹeɪnʒ ɡɹeɪnɪŋ. ðəɹ wɑz wʌn tʃɛɹ, ɑn ə sɪlk kɑɹpət woʊvən ɪn bɝdz ən flaʊɝz, ən wʌn lɑɹdʒ kæbənət meɪɾ ɪn ə sɝkəl. foʊldɪŋ skɹinz meɪd nu wɔlz.

He was led into another room. He thought the furniture here had to have been brought by Turak. It seemed to be made of curves, with no straight lines at all, and the wood was polished to bring out strange graining. There was one chair, on a silk carpet woven in birds and flowers, and one large cabinet made in a circle. Folding screens made new walls.

ðə mæn wɪð ðə bɹeɪɾ oʊpən ðə dɔɹz ə ðə kæbənət tə ɹɪvil ʃɛlvz hoʊldɪŋ ən ɑɾ əsɔɹtmən ə fɪɡjɝinz, kʌps, boʊlz, veɪsəz, fɪfti dɪfɹən θɪŋz, noʊ tu əlaɪk ɪn saɪz əɹ ʃeɪp. doʊmənz bɹɛθ kɑɾ əz tʃɹɑk kɛɹfəli sɛt ðə dɪsk bɪsaɪɾ ɪts ɪɡzæk twɪn.

The man with the braid opened the doors of the cabinet to reveal shelves holding an odd assortment of figurines, cups, bowls, vases, fifty different things, no two alike in size or shape. Domon's breath caught as Turak carefully set the disk beside its exact twin.

"kwəndɪlɝ," tʃɹɑk sɛd. "ðæɾ ɪz wʌɾ aɪ kəlɛkt, tʃɹeɪɾɝ. oʊnli ði ɛmpɹɛs hɝsɛlf əz ə faɪnɝ kəlɛkʃən."

"Cuendillar," Turak said. "That is what I collect, trader. Only the Empress herself has a finer collection."

doʊmənz aɪz ɔlmoʊs pɑpt aʊɾ ə hɪz hɛd. ɪf ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɑn ðoʊz ʃɛlvz wɑz tʃɹuli kwəndɪlɝ, ɪt wɑz ɪnʌf tə baɪ ə kɪŋdəm, əɹ ət ðə lis tə faʊn ə ɡɹeɪt haʊs. ivən ə kɪŋ maɪt bɛɡɝ hɪmsɛlf tə baɪ soʊ mʌtʃ ʌv ɪt, ɪf i ivən nu wɛɹ tə faɪn soʊ mʌtʃ. hi pʊɾ ɑn ə smaɪl.

Domon's eyes almost popped out of his head. If everything on those shelves was truly cuendillar, it was enough to buy a kingdom, or at the least to found a great House. Even a king might beggar himself to buy so much of it, if he even knew where to find so much. He put on a smile.

"haɪ lɔɹd, pliz æksɛp ðɪs pis əz ə ɡɪft." hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə lɛɾ ɪt ɡoʊ, bʌt ðət wɑz bɛɾɝ ðən æŋɡɝɪŋ ðɪs sintʃæn. meɪbi ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz wɪl tʃeɪs ɪm naʊ. "aɪ də bi bʌɾ ə sɪmpəl tʃɹeɪɾɝ. aɪ wɑn oʊnli tə tʃɹeɪd. lemi seɪl, ən aɪ də pɹɑməs ðət - "

"High Lord, please accept this piece as a gift." He did not want to let it go, but that was better than angering this Seanchan. Maybe the Darkfriends will chase him now. "I do be but a simple trader. I want only to trade. Let me sail, and I do promise that - "

tʃɹɑks ɪkspɹɛʃən nɛvɝ tʃeɪnʒd, bʌt ðə mæn wɪð ðə bɹeɪd kʌt doʊmən ɔf wɪð ə snæpt, "ənʃeɪvən dɔɡ! jə spik ʌv ɡɪvɪŋ ðə haɪ lɔɹd wʌt kæptən ɛdʒiənɪn əz ɔlɹɛɾi ɡɪvən. jə bɑɹɡən, əz ɪf ðə haɪ lɔɹd wɝ ə - ə mɝtʃənt! jəl bi fleɪɾ əlaɪv oʊvɝ naɪn deɪz, dɔɡ, ən - " ðə bɛɹəs moʊʃən ə tʃɹɑks fɪŋɡɝ saɪləns hɪm.

Turak's expression never changed, but the man with the braid cut Domon off with a snapped, "Unshaven dog! You speak of giving the High Lord what Captain Egeanin has already given. You bargain, as if the High Lord were a - a merchant! You will be flayed alive over nine days, dog, and - " The barest motion of Turak's finger silenced him.

"aɪ kænɑɾ əlaʊ jə tə liv mi, tʃɹeɪɾɝ," ðə haɪ lɔɹd sɛd. "ɪn ðɪs ʃæɾoʊd læn ʌv oʊθ-bɹeɪkɝz, aɪ faɪnd nʌn u kən kənvɝs wɪð ə mæn ə sɛnsɪbɪlɪɾiz. bʌt jə ɑɹ ə kəlɛktɝ. pɝhæps jəɹ kɑnvɝseɪʃən wɪl bi ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ." hi tʊk ðə tʃɛɹ, lɑlɪŋ bæk ɪn ɪts kɝvz tə stʌɾi doʊmən.

"I cannot allow you to leave me, trader," the High Lord said. "In this shadowed land of oath-breakers, I find none who can converse with a man of sensibilities. But you are a collector. Perhaps your conversation will be interesting." He took the chair, lolling back in its curves to study Domon.

doʊmən pʊɾ ɑn wʌɾ i hoʊpt wɑz ən ɪnɡɹeɪʃieɪɾɪŋ smaɪl. "haɪ lɔɹd, aɪ də bi ə sɪmpəl tʃɹeɪɾɝ, ə sɪmpəl mæn. aɪ də noʊ hæv ðə weɪ ʌv tɔkɪŋ wɪð ɡɹeɪt lɔɹdz."

Domon put on what he hoped was an ingratiating smile. "High Lord, I do be a simple trader, a simple man. I do no have the way of talking with great Lords."

ðə mæn wɪð ðə bɹeɪd ɡlɛɹɾ ət hɪm, bʌt tʃɹɑk sim nɑt tə hɪɹ. fɹəm bɪhaɪnd wʌn ə ðə skɹinz, ə slɪm, pɹɪɾi jʌŋ wʊmən əpɪɹɾ ɑn kwɪk fit tə nil bɪsaɪd ðə haɪ lɔɹd, ɔfɝɪŋ ə lækɝd tʃɹeɪ bɛɹɪŋ ə sɪŋɡəl kʌp, θɪn ən hændəlləs, ʌv səm stimɪŋ blæk lɪkwəd. hɝ dɑɹk, ɹaʊn feɪs wɑz veɪɡli ɹɛmənɪsən ə ðə si foʊk. tʃɹɑk tʊk ðə kʌp kɛɹfəli ɪn ɪz lɔŋ-neɪl fɪŋɡɝz, nɛvɝ lʊkɪŋ ət ðə jʌŋ wʊmən, ən ɪnheɪl ðə fjumz. doʊmən tʊk wʌn lʊk ət ðə ɡɝl ən pʊld ɪz aɪz əweɪ wɪð ə stʃɹæŋɡəld ɡæsp; hɝ waɪt sɪlk ɹoʊb wɑz ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð flaʊɝz, bʌt soʊ ʃɪɹ i kəd si ɹaɪt θɹu ɪt, ən ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ bɪniθ bʌɾ əɹ oʊn slɪmnəs.

The man with the braid glared at him, but Turak seemed not to hear. From behind one of the screens, a slim, pretty young woman appeared on quick feet to kneel beside the High Lord, offering a lacquered tray bearing a single cup, thin and handleless, of some steaming black liquid. Her dark, round face was vaguely reminiscent of the Sea Folk. Turak took the cup carefully in his long-nailed fingers, never looking at the young woman, and inhaled the fumes. Domon took one look at the girl and pulled his eyes away with a strangled gasp; her white silk robe was embroidered with flowers, but so sheer he could see right through it, and there was nothing beneath but her own slimness.

"ði ɝoʊmə ʌv kæf," tʃɹɑk sɛd, "ɪz ɔlmoʊst əz ɛndʒɔɪəbəl əz ðə fleɪvɝ. naʊ, tʃɹeɪɾɝ. aɪ hæv lɝn ðət kwəndɪlɝ ɪz ivən mɔɹ ɹɛɹ hɪɹ ðən ɪn sintʃæn. tɛl mi haʊ ə sɪmpəl tʃɹeɪɾɝ keɪm tə pəzɛs ə pis." hi sɪpt ɪz kæf ən weɪɾəd.

"The aroma of kaf," Turak said, "is almost as enjoyable as the flavor. Now, trader. I have learned that cuendillar is even more rare here than in Seanchan. Tell me how a simple trader came to possess a piece." He sipped his kaf and waited.

doʊmən tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ ən sɛɾ əbaʊt tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə laɪ hɪz weɪ aʊɾ ə fɑlm.

Domon took a deep breath and set about trying to lie his way out of Falme.


tʃæptɝ θɝɾi


CHAPTER 30

deɪz deɪmɑɹ


Daes Dae'mar

ɪn ðə ɹum ʃɛɹd baɪ hʊɹɪn ən lɔɪəl, ɹænd pɪɹd θɹu ðə wɪndoʊ ət ði ɔɹɾɝd laɪnz ən tɛɹəsəz ə kɛɹhin, ðə stoʊn bɪldɪŋz ən sleɪt ɹufs. hi kəd nɑt si ði ɪluməneɪɾɝz' tʃæptɝ haʊs; ivən ɪf hjudʒ taʊɝz ən ɡɹeɪt lɔɹdz' haʊsəz hæd nɑt bɪn ɪn ðə weɪ, ðə sɪɾi wɔlz wʊɾə pɹɪvɛntɪɾ ɪt. ði ɪluməneɪɾɝz wɝ ɑn ɛvɹiwʌnz tʌŋz ɪn ðə sɪɾi, ivən naʊ, deɪz æftɝ ðə naɪt wən ðeɪ hæd lɔftəɾ oʊnli wʌn naɪtfloʊɝ ɪndə ðə skaɪ, ən ðəɾ ɝli. ə dʌzən dɪfɹən vɝʒənz ə ðə skændəl wɝ biɪŋ toʊld, dɪskaʊntɪŋ maɪnɝ vɛɹieɪʃənz, bʌt nʌn kloʊs tə ðə tʃɹuθ.

In the room shared by Hurin and Loial, Rand peered through the window at the ordered lines and terraces of Cairhien, the stone buildings and slate roofs. He could not see the Illuminators' chapter house; even if huge towers and great lords' houses had not been in the way, the city walls would have prevented it. The Illuminators were on everyone's tongues in the city, even now, days after the night when they had lofted only one nightflower into the sky, and that early. A dozen different versions of the scandal were being told, discounting minor variations, but none close to the truth.

ɹænd tɝn əweɪ. hi hoʊp noʊ wʌn hæd bɪn hɝɾ ɪn ðə faɪɝ, bʌt ði ɪluməneɪɾɝz hæd nɑt soʊ fɑɹ ədmɪɾəd ðəɹ hæd bɪn ə faɪɝ. ðeɪ wɝ ə kloʊs-maʊð lɑɾ əbaʊt wʌt wɛn ɑn ɪnsaɪd ðɛɹ tʃæptɝ haʊs.

Rand turned away. He hoped no one had been hurt in the fire, but the Illuminators had not so far admitted there had been a fire. They were a close-mouthed lot about what went on inside their chapter house.

"aɪ wɪl teɪk ðə nɛkst wɑtʃ," hi toʊl hʊɹɪn, "æz sun əz aɪ kʌm bæk."

"I will take the next watch," he told Hurin, "as soon as I come back."

"ðɛɹ ɪz noʊ nid, maɪ lɔɹd." hʊɹɪn baʊɾ əz dipli əz ɛni kɛɹhinɪn. "aɪ kən kip wɑtʃ. tʃɹuli, maɪ lɔɹd nid nɑt tʃɹʌbəl hɪmsɛlf."

"There is no need, my Lord." Hurin bowed as deeply as any Cairhienin. "I can keep watch. Truly, my Lord need not trouble himself."

ɹænd dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ ən ɪkstʃeɪnʒd lʊks wɪð lɔɪəl. ði oʊɡiɝ oʊnli ʃɹʌɡd. ðə snɪfɝ wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ mɔɹ fɔɹməl ɛvɹi deɪ ðeɪ ɹɪmeɪn ɪn kɛɹhin; ði oʊɡiɝ sɪmpli kɑmɛntəd ðət hjumənz ɔfən æktəɾ ɑdli.

Rand drew a deep breath and exchanged looks with Loial. The Ogier only shrugged. The sniffer was growing more formal every day they remained in Cairhien; the Ogier simply commented that humans often acted oddly.

"hʊɹɪn," ɹænd sɛd, "ju juz tə kɔl mi lɔɹd ɹænd, ən jə juz nɑt tə baʊ ɛvɹi taɪm aɪ lʊkt ət ju." aɪ wɑn ɪm tə ʌnbɪn ən kɔl mi lɔɹd ɹænd əɡɛn, hi θɔt wɪð əmeɪzmənt. lɔɹd ɹænd! laɪt, wɪv tə ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə hɪɹ bɪfɔɹ aɪ stɑɹt wɑntɪŋ ɪm tə baʊ. "wɪl jə pliz sɪt daʊn? jə meɪk mi taɪɝd, lʊkɪŋ ət ju."

"Hurin," Rand said, "you used to call me Lord Rand, and you used not to bow every time I looked at you." I want him to unbend and call me Lord Rand again, he thought with amazement. Lord Rand! Light, we have to get out of here before I start wanting him to bow. "Will you please sit down? You make me tired, looking at you."

hʊɹɪn stʊd wɪð ɪz bæk stɪf, jɛɾ əpɪɹd ɹɛɾi tə lip tə pɝfɔɹm ɛni tæsk ɹænd maɪt ɹɪkwɛst. hi niðɝ sæt daʊn nɔɹ ɹɪlæks naʊ. "ɪt wʊdn bi pɹɑpɝ, maɪ lɔɹd. wɪv tə ʃoʊ ðiz kɛɹhinɪn wi noʊ haʊ tə bi ɛvɹi bɪɾ əz pɹɑpɝ əz - "

Hurin stood with his back stiff, yet appeared ready to leap to perform any task Rand might request. He neither sat down nor relaxed now. "It wouldn't be proper, my Lord. We have to show these Cairhienin we know how to be every bit as proper as - "

"wɪl jə stɑp seɪɪŋ ðæt!" ɹænd ʃaʊɾəd.

"Will you stop saying that!" Rand shouted.

"æz jə wɪʃ, maɪ lɔɹd."

"As you wish, my Lord."

ɪt wɑz ən ɛfɝt fəɹ ɹænd nɑt tə saɪ əɡɛn. "hʊɹɪn, aɪm sɑɹi. aɪ ʃəd nɑɾ əv ʃaʊɾəd ət ju."

It was an effort for Rand not to sigh again. "Hurin, I'm sorry. I should not have shouted at you."

"ɪts jəɹ ɹaɪt, maɪ lɔɹd," hʊɹɪn sɛd sɪmpli. "ɪf aɪ doʊn də ðə weɪ jə wɑnt, ɪts jəɹ ɹaɪt tə ʃaʊt."

"It's your right, my Lord," Hurin said simply. "If I don't do the way you want, it's your right to shout."

ɹænd stɛp təwɔɹd ðə snɪfɝ wɪð ði ɪntɛntʃən ʌv ɡɹæbɪŋ ðə mænz kɑlɝ ən ʃeɪkɪŋ hɪm.

Rand stepped toward the sniffer with the intention of grabbing the man's collar and shaking him.

ə nɑk ɑn ðə kənɛktɪŋ dɔɹ tə ɹændz ɹum fɹoʊz əm ɔl, bʌt ɹænd wɑz pliz tə si ðət hʊɹɪn dɪd nɑt weɪt tə æsk pɝmɪʃən bɪfɔɹ pɪkɪŋ ʌp ɪz sɔɹd. ðə hɛɹən-mɑɹk bleɪd wɑz ət ɹændz weɪst; ɡoʊɪŋ aʊt, hi tʌtʃt ɪts hɪlt. hi weɪɾəd fəɹ lɔɪəl tə sit hɪmsɛlf ɑn ɪz lɔŋ bɛd, ɝeɪnʒɪŋ ɪz lɛɡz ən ðə teɪlz ə hɪz koʊt tə fɝðɝ əbskjʊɹ ðə blæŋkət-kʌvɝd tʃɛst ʌndɝ ðə bɛd, ðən jæŋkt oʊpən ðə dɔɹ.

A knock on the connecting door to Rand's room froze them all, but Rand was pleased to see that Hurin did not wait to ask permission before picking up his sword. The heron-mark blade was at Rand's waist; going out, he touched its hilt. He waited for Loial to seat himself on his long bed, arranging his legs and the tails of his coat to further obscure the blanket-covered chest under the bed, then yanked open the door.

ði ɪnkipɝ stʊd ðɛɹ, ɹɑkɪŋ wɪð iɡɝnəs ən pʊʃɪŋ ɪz tʃɹeɪ ət ɹænd. tu sil pɑɹtʃməns leɪ ɑn ðə tʃɹeɪ. "fɝɡɪv mi, maɪ lɔɹd," kueɪli sɛd bɹɛθləsli. "aɪ kəd nɑt weɪɾ əntɪl jə keɪm daʊn, ən ðən jə wɝ nɑɾ ɪn jəɹ oʊn ɹum, ən - ænd. . . . fɝɡɪv mi, bʌt. . . ." hi dʒɪɡɡəl ðə tʃɹeɪ.

The innkeeper stood there, rocking with eagerness and pushing his tray at Rand. Two sealed parchments lay on the tray. "Forgive me, my Lord," Cuale said breathlessly. "I could not wait until you came down, and then you were not in your own room, and - and. . . . Forgive me, but. . . ." He jiggled the tray.

ɹænd snætʃt ði ɪnvɪteɪʃənz - ðəɹ hæd bɪn soʊ mɛni - wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ ət ðɛm, tʊk ði ɪnkipɝz ɑɹm, ən tɝn ɪm təwɔɹd ðə dɔɹ tə ðə hɔl. "θæŋk ju, mæstɝ kueɪli, fəɹ teɪkɪŋ ðə tʃɹʌbəl. ɪf jəl liv əs əloʊn, naʊ, pliz. . . ."

Rand snatched the invitations - there had been so many - without looking at them, took the innkeeper's arm, and turned him toward the door to the hall. "Thank you, Master Cuale, for taking the trouble. If you'll leave us alone, now, please. . . ."

"bʌt, maɪ lɔɹd," kueɪli pɹətɛstəd, "ðiz ɑɹ fɹəm - "

"But, my Lord," Cuale protested, "these are from - "

"θæŋk ju." ɹænd pʊʃt ðə mæn ɪndə ðə hɔl ən pʊl ðə dɔɹ ʃʌt fɝmli. hi tɔs ðə pɑɹtʃməns ɑntu ðə teɪbəl. "hi hæzən dʌn ðət bɪfɔɹ. lɔɪəl, dʒju θɪŋk i wɑz lɪsnɪŋ ət ðə dɔɹ bɪfɔɹ i nɑkt?"

"Thank you." Rand pushed the man into the hall and pulled the door shut firmly. He tossed the parchments onto the table. "He hasn't done that before. Loial, do you think he was listening at the door before he knocked?"

"ju ɑɹ stɑɹɾɪŋ tə θɪŋk laɪk ðiz kɛɹhinɪn." ði oʊɡiɝ læft, bʌɾ ɪz ɪɹz twɪtʃt θɔtfəli ən i æɾəd, "stɪl, hiz kɛɹhinɪn, soʊ hi meɪ wɛl əv bɪn. aɪ doʊn θɪŋk wi sɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ i ʃəd nɑɾ əv hɝd."

"You are starting to think like these Cairhienin." The Ogier laughed, but his ears twitched thoughtfully and he added, "Still, he is Cairhienin, so he may well have been. I don't think we said anything he should not have heard."

ɹænd tʃɹaɪd tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ. nʌn ə ðɛm hæd mɛnʃən ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ, əɹ tʃɹɑləks, əɹ dɑɹkfɹɛnz. wən i faʊn hɪmsɛlf wʌndɝɪŋ wʌt kueɪli kəd meɪk ʌv wʌt ðeɪ æktʃəli  hæd sɛd, hi ɡeɪv hɪmsɛlf ə ʃeɪk. "ðɪs pleɪs ɪz ɡɛɾɪŋ tə ju, tu," hi mʌɾɝd tə hɪmsɛlf.

Rand tried to remember. None of them had mentioned the Horn of Valere, or Trollocs, or Darkfriends. When he found himself wondering what Cuale could make of what they actually had said, he gave himself a shake. "This place is getting to you, too," he muttered to himself.

"maɪ lɔɹd?" hʊɹɪn hæd pɪkt ʌp ðə sil pɑɹtʃməns ən wɑz ɡeɪzɪŋ waɪd-aɪɾ ət ðə silz. "maɪ lɔɹd, ðiz ɑɹ fɹəm lɔɹd bɑɹθeɪnz, haɪ siɾ ə haʊs dəmədʒɹd, ən fɹʌm" - hɪz vɔɪs dʒɹɑpt wɪð ɑ - "ðə kɪŋ."

"My Lord?" Hurin had picked up the sealed parchments and was gazing wide-eyed at the seals. "My Lord, these are from Lord Barthanes, High Seat of House Damodred, and from" - his voice dropped with awe - "the King."

ɹænd weɪvd əm əweɪ. "ðeɪ stɪl ɡoʊ ɪn ðə faɪɝ laɪk ðə ɹɛst. ənoʊpənd."

Rand waved them away. "They still go in the fire like the rest. Unopened."

"bʌt, maɪ lɔɹd!"

"But, my Lord!"

"hʊɹɪn," ɹænd sɛd peɪʃənli, "ju ən lɔɪəl bɪtwin juv ɪkspleɪn ðɪs ɡɹeɪt ɡeɪm tə mi. ɪf aɪ ɡoʊ wɛɹɛvɝ ɪts ðeɪv ɪnvaɪɾəd mi, ðə kɛɹhinɪn wɪl ɹid sʌmθɪŋ ɪndə ɪɾ ən θɪŋk aɪm pɑɹɾ ə sʌmbɑɾiz plɑt. ɪf aɪ doʊnt ɡoʊ, ðəl ɹɛd sʌmθɪŋ ɪndə ðæt. ɪf aɪ sɛn bæk ən ænsɝ, ðəl dɪɡ fəɹ minɪŋ ɪn ɪt, ən ðə seɪm ɪf aɪ doʊn ænsɝ. ən sɪns hæf ə kɛɹhin əpɛɹənli spaɪz ɑn ði ʌðɝ hæf, ɛvɹibɑɾi noʊz wʌɾ aɪ du. aɪ bɝn ðə fɝs tu, ən əl bɝn ðiz, dʒʌs laɪk ɔl ði ʌðɝz." wʌn deɪ ðəɹ hæd bɪn twɛlv ɪn ðə paɪl i tɔst ɪndə ðə kɑmən-ɹum faɪɝpleɪs, silz ənbɹoʊkən. "wʌtɛvɝ ðeɪ meɪk ʌv ɪt, ət list ɪts ðə seɪm fəɹ ɛvɹibɑɾi. aɪm nɑt fəɹ ɛniwʌn ɪn kɛɹhin, ən aɪm nɑɾ əɡɛnst ɛniwʌn."

"Hurin," Rand said patiently, "you and Loial between you have explained this Great Game to me. If I go wherever it is they've invited me, the Cairhienin will read something into it and think I am part of somebody's plot. If I don't go, they'll read something into that. If I send back an answer, they will dig for meaning in it, and the same if I don't answer. And since half of Cairhien apparently spies on the other half, everybody knows what I do. I burned the first two, and I will burn these, just like all the others." One day there had been twelve in the pile he tossed into the common-room fireplace, seals unbroken. "Whatever they make of it, at least it's the same for everybody. I am not for anyone in Cairhien, and I am not against anyone."

"aɪ hæv tʃɹaɪd tə tɛl ju," lɔɪəl sɛd, "aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ɪt wɝks ðət weɪ. wʌtɛvɝ jə du, kɛɹhinɪn wɪl si səm sɔɹɾ ə plɑɾ ɪn ɪt. ət list, ðəɾ ɪz wʌɾ ɛldɝ heɪmən ɔlweɪz sɛd."

"I have tried to tell you," Loial said, "I don't think it works that way. Whatever you do, Cairhienin will see some sort of plot in it. At least, that is what Elder Haman always said."

hʊɹɪn hɛl ðə sild ɪnvɪteɪʃənz aʊt tə ɹænd əz ɪf ɔfɝɪŋ ɡoʊld. "maɪ lɔɹd, ðɪs wʌn bɛɹz ðə pɝsənəl sil ʌv ɡɔlʒɹiən. hɪz pɝsənəl sil, maɪ lɔɹd. ən ðɪs wʌn ðə pɝsənəl sil ə lɔɹd bɑɹθeɪnz, hu ɪz nɛks tə ðə kɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ɪn paʊɝ. maɪ lɔɹd, bɝn ðiz, ən jə meɪk ɛnəmiz əz paʊɝfəl əz jə kən faɪnd. bɝnɪŋ ðɛmz wɝk soʊ fɑɹ kəz ði ʌðɝ haʊsəz ɑɹ ɔl weɪɾɪŋ tə si wʌt jəɹ ʌp tə, ən θɪŋkɪŋ jə mʌst əv paʊɝfəl ælaɪz tə ɹɪsk ɪnsʌltɪŋ ðɛm. bʌt lɔɹd bɑɹθeɪnz - ən ðə kɪŋ! ɪnsəl ðɛm, ən ðəl æk fəɹ ʃʊɹ."

Hurin held the sealed invitations out to Rand as if offering gold. "My Lord, this one bears the personal seal of Galldrian. His personal seal, my Lord. And this one the personal seal of Lord Barthanes, who is next to the King himself in power. My Lord, burn these, and you make enemies as powerful as you can find. Burning them's worked so far because the other Houses are all waiting to see what you're up to, and thinking you must have powerful allies to risk insulting them. But Lord Barthanes - and the King! Insult them, and they'll act for sure."

ɹænd skɹʌbd ɪz hænz θɹu hɪz hɛɹ. "wʌɾ ɪf aɪ ɹɛfjus əm boʊθ?"

Rand scrubbed his hands through his hair. "What if I refuse them both?"

"ɪt woʊnt wɝk, maɪ lɔɹd. ɛvɹi læs haʊs əz sɛn jə ən ɪnvɪteɪʃən, naʊ. ɪf jə dɪklaɪn ðiz - wɛl, fəɹ ʃʊɹ ət list wʌn ə ði ʌðɝ haʊsəz wɪl fɪɡjɝ, ɪf jəɹ nɑɾ əlaɪd wɪð ðə kɪŋ əɹ lɔɹd bɑɹθeɪnz, ðən ðeɪ kən ænsɝ jəɹ ɪnsəlt ə bɝnɪŋ ðɛɹ ɪnvɪteɪʃən. maɪ lɔɹd, aɪ hɪɹ ðə haʊsəz ɪn kɛɹhin jus kɪlɝz, naʊ. ə naɪf ɪn ðə stʃɹit. ən æɹoʊ fɹəm ə ɹuftɑp. pɔɪzən slɪpt ɪn jəɹ waɪn."

"It won't work, my Lord. Every last House has sent you an invitation, now. If you decline these - well, for sure at least one of the other Houses will figure, if you're not allied with the King or Lord Barthanes, then they can answer your insult of burning their invitation. My Lord, I hear the Houses in Cairhien use killers, now. A knife in the street. An arrow from a rooftop. Poison slipped in your wine."

"ju kəɾ æksɛpt əm boʊθ," lɔɪəl sədʒɛstəd. "aɪ noʊ jə doʊnt wɑn tə, ɹænd, bʌɾ ɪt maɪɾ ivən bi fʌn. ən ivnɪŋ əɾ ə lɔɹdz mænɝ, əɹ ivən ət ðə ɹɔɪəl pæləs. ɹænd, ðə ʃaɪnɝənz bɪlivd ɪn ju."

"You could accept them both," Loial suggested. "I know you don't want to, Rand, but it might even be fun. An evening at a lord's manor, or even at the Royal Palace. Rand, the Shienarans believed in you."

ɹænd ɡɹɪməst. hi nu ɪt hæd bɪn tʃæns ðət ðə ʃaɪnɝənz θɔɾ i wɑz ə lɔɹd; ə tʃæns laɪknəs ə neɪmz, ə ɹumɝ əmʌŋ ðə sɝvəns, ən mɔɪɹeɪn ən ði æmɪɝlɪn stɝɪŋ ɪɾ ɔl. bʌt səlin hæd bɪlivd ɪt, tu. meɪbi ʃɪl bi ət wʌn ə ðiz.

Rand grimaced. He knew it had been chance that the Shienarans thought he was a lord; a chance likeness of names, a rumor among the servants, and Moiraine and the Amyrlin stirring it all. But Selene had believed it, too. Maybe she'll be at one of these.

hʊɹɪn wɑz ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd vaɪələnli, ðoʊ. "bɪldɝ, jə doʊnt noʊ deɪz deɪmɑɹ əz wɛl əz jə θɪŋk jə du. nɑt ðə weɪ ðeɪ pleɪ ɪɾ ɪn kɛɹhin, nɑt naʊ. wɪð moʊs haʊzɪz, ɪt wʊdn mæɾɝ. ivən wən ðəɹ plɑɾɪŋ əɡɛnst itʃ ʌðɝ tə ðə naɪf, ðeɪ æk laɪk ðeɪ ɑɹənt, aʊt wɛɹ ɛvɹibɑɾi kən si. bʌt nɑt ðiz tu. haʊs dəmədʒɹd hɛl ðə θɹoʊn əntɪl leɪmən lɔst ɪt, ən ðeɪ wɑn ɪt bæk. ðə kɪŋ wəd kɹʌʃ ðɛm, ɪf ðeɪ wɝnt nɪɹli əz paʊɝfəl əz i ɪz. jə kæn faɪn bɪɾɝɝ ɹaɪvəlz ðən haʊs ɹieɪɾən ən haʊs dəmədʒɹd. ɪf maɪ lɔɹɾ æksɛps boʊθ, boʊθ haʊsəz wɪl noʊ ɪɾ əz sun əz i sɛnz ɪz ænsɝz, ən ðəl boʊθ θɪŋk hiz pɑɹɾ ə səm plɑt baɪ ði ʌðɝ əɡɛns ðɛm. ðəl juz ðə naɪf ən ðə pɔɪzən əz kwɪk əz lʊk ət ju."

Hurin was shaking his head violently, though. "Builder, you don't know Daes Dae'mar as well as you think you do. Not the way they play it in Cairhien, not now. With most Houses, it wouldn't matter. Even when they're plotting against each other to the knife, they act like they aren't, out where everybody can see. But not these two. House Damodred held the throne until Laman lost it, and they want it back. The King would crush them, if they weren't nearly as powerful as he is. You can't find bitterer rivals than House Riatin and House Damodred. If my Lord accepts both, both Houses will know it as soon as he sends his answers, and they'll both think he's part of some plot by the other against them. They'll use the knife and the poison as quick as look at you."

"æn aɪ səpoʊz," ɹænd ɡɹaʊld, "ɪf aɪ oʊnli æksɛpt wʌn, ði ʌðɝ wɪl θɪŋk aɪm əlaɪd wɪð ðət haʊs." hʊɹɪn nɑɾəd. "æn ðəl pɹɑbli tʃɹaɪ tə kɪl mi tə stɑp wʌtɛvɝ aɪm ɪnvɑlvd ɪn." hʊɹɪn nɑɾəd əɡɛn. "ðɛn juv ɛni sədʒɛstʃən əz tə haʊ aɪ əvɔɪɾ ɛni ʌv əm wɑntɪŋ tə si mi dɛd?" hʊɹɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "aɪ wɪʃ aɪd nɛvɝ bɝn ðoʊz fɝs tu."

"And I suppose," Rand growled, "if I only accept one, the other will think I'm allied with that House." Hurin nodded. "And they will probably try to kill me to stop whatever I'm involved in." Hurin nodded again. "Then do you have any suggestion as to how I avoid any of them wanting to see me dead?" Hurin shook his head. "I wish I'd never burned those first two."

"jɛs, maɪ lɔɹd. bʌɾ ɪt wʊdn əv meɪd mʌtʃ dɪfɝəns, aɪm ɡɛsɪŋ. huɛvɝ jə æksɛptɪɾ əɹ ɹɪdʒɛktɪd, ðiz kɛɹhinɪn wəd si sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ɪt."

"Yes, my Lord. But it wouldn't have made much difference, I'm guessing. Whoever you accepted or rejected, these Cairhienin would see something in it."

ɹænd hɛld aʊɾ ɪz hænd, ən hʊɹɪn leɪd ðə tu foʊldəd pɑɹtʃməns ɪn ɪt. ðə wʌn wɑz sild, nɑt wɪð ðə tʃɹi ən kɹaʊn ə haʊs dəmədʒɹd, bʌt wɪð bɑɹθeɪnzəz tʃɑɹdʒɪŋ bɔɹ. ði ʌðɝ bɔɹ ɡɔlʒɹiənz stæɡ. pɝsənəl silz. əpɛɹənli hi hæd mænədʒ tə ɹaʊs ɪntʃɹəst ɪn ðə haɪəs kɔɹɾɝz baɪ duɪŋ nʌθɪŋ əɾ ɔl.

Rand held out his hand, and Hurin laid the two folded parchments in it. The one was sealed, not with the Tree and Crown of House Damodred, but with Barthanes's Charging Boar. The other bore Galldrian's Stag. Personal seals. Apparently he had managed to rouse interest in the highest quarters by doing nothing at all.

"ðiz pipəl ɑɹ kɹeɪzi," hi sɛd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə θɪŋk ʌv ə weɪ aʊɾ ə ðɪs.

"These people are crazy," he said, trying to think of a way out of this.

"jɛs, maɪ lɔɹd."

"Yes, my Lord."

"aɪ wɪl lɛɾ əm si mi ɪn ðə kɑmən ɹum wɪð ðiz," hi sɛd sloʊli. wʌtɛvɝ wɑz sin ɪn ðə kɑmən ɹum ət mɪddeɪ wɑz noʊn ɪn tɛn haʊsəz bɪfɔɹ naɪtfɔl, ən ɪn ɔl ə ðɛm baɪ deɪbɹeɪk nɛkst. "aɪ woʊn bɹeɪk ðə silz. ðət weɪ, ðəl noʊ aɪ hæv nɑɾ ænsɝɾ iðɝ wʌn jɛt. əz lɔŋ əz ðeɪ ɑɹ weɪɾɪŋ tə si wɪtʃ weɪ aɪ dʒʌmp, meɪbi aɪ kən ɝn ə fju mɔɹ deɪz. ɪŋtʃɹ əz tə kʌm sun. hiz tə."

"I will let them see me in the common room with these," he said slowly. Whatever was seen in the common room at midday was known in ten Houses before nightfall, and in all of them by daybreak next. "I won't break the seals. That way, they will know I have not answered either one yet. As long as they are waiting to see which way I jump, maybe I can earn a few more days. Ingtar has to come soon. He has to."

"naʊ ðəɾ ɪz θɪŋkɪŋ laɪk ə kɛɹhinɪn, maɪ lɔɹd," hʊɹɪn sɛd, ɡɹɪnɪŋ.

"Now that is thinking like a Cairhienin, my Lord," Hurin said, grinning.

ɹænd ɡeɪv ɪm ə saʊɝ lʊk, ðən stʌf ðə pɑɹtʃməns ɪndə hɪz pɑkəɾ ɑn tɑp ə səlinz lɛɾɝz. "lɛts ɡoʊ, lɔɪəl. meɪbi ɪŋtʃɹ əz ɝaɪvd."

Rand gave him a sour look, then stuffed the parchments into his pocket on top of Selene's letters. "Let's go, Loial. Maybe Ingtar has arrived."

wən i ən lɔɪəl ɹitʃt ðə kɑmən ɹum, noʊ mæn ən wʊmən ɪn ɪt lʊkt ət ɹænd. kueɪli wɑz pɑlɪʃɪŋ ə sɪlvɝ tʃɹeɪ əz ɪf ɪz laɪf dɪpɛndəɾ ɑn ɪts ɡlim. ðə sɝvɪŋ ɡɝlz hɝid bɪtwin ðə teɪbəlz əz ɪf ɹænd ən ði oʊɡiɝ dɪd nɑɾ ɪɡzɪst. ɛvɹi læs pɝsən ət ðə teɪbəlz stɛɹɾ ɪndə hɪz əɹ əɹ mʌɡ əz ɪf ðə sikɹəts ə paʊɝ leɪ ɪn waɪn əɹ eɪl. nɑt wʌn ə ðɛm sɛɾ ə wɝd.

When he and Loial reached the common room, no man and woman in it looked at Rand. Cuale was polishing a silver tray as if his life depended on its gleam. The serving girls hurried between the tables as if Rand and the Ogier did not exist. Every last person at the tables stared into his or her mug as if the secrets of power lay in wine or ale. Not one of them said a word.

æftɝ ə moʊmənt, hi pʊl ðə tu ɪnvɪteɪʃənz fɹəm ɪz pɑkəɾ ən stʌɾid ðə silz, ðən stʌk əm bæk. kueɪli ɡeɪv ə lɪɾəl dʒʌmp əz ɹænd stɑɹɾəd fəɹ ðə dɔɹ. bɪfɔɹ ɪt kloʊz bɪhaɪn hɪm, hi hɝd kɑnvɝseɪʃən spɹɪŋ ʌp əɡɛn.

After a moment, he pulled the two invitations from his pocket and studied the seals, then stuck them back. Cuale gave a little jump as Rand started for the door. Before it closed behind him, he heard conversation spring up again.

ɹænd stʃɹoʊd daʊn ðə stʃɹit soʊ fæs ðət lɔɪəl dɪd nɑɾ əv tə ʃɔɹɾən ɪz stʃɹaɪd tə steɪ bɪsaɪd hɪm. "wi hæv tə faɪn ə weɪ aʊɾ ə ðə sɪɾi, lɔɪəl. ðɪs tʃɹɪk wɪð ði ɪnvɪteɪʃənz kænt wɝk mɔɹ ðən tu əɹ θɹi deɪz. ɪf ɪŋtʃɹ dʌzn kʌm baɪ ðɛn, wi mʌs liv ɛniweɪ."

Rand strode down the street so fast that Loial did not have to shorten his stride to stay beside him. "We have to find a way out of the city, Loial. This trick with the invitations can't work more than two or three days. If Ingtar doesn't come by then, we must leave anyway."

"əɡɹid," lɔɪəl sɛd.

"Agreed," Loial said.

"bʌt haʊ?"

"But how?"

lɔɪəl bɪɡæn tɪkɪŋ ɔf pɔɪns ɑn ɪz θɪk fɪŋɡɝz. "feɪn ɪz aʊt ðɛɹ, əɹ ðəɹ wəd nɑɾ əv bɪn tʃɹɑləks ɪn ðə fɔɹɡeɪt. ɪf wi ɹaɪɾ aʊt, ðəl bi ɑn əs əz sun əz wəɹ aʊɾ ə saɪɾ ə ðə sɪɾi. ɪf wi tʃɹævəl wɪð ə mɝtʃən tʃɹeɪn, ðəl sɝɾənli ətæk ɪt." noʊ mɝtʃənt wəɾ əv mɔɹ ðən faɪv əɹ sɪks ɡɑɹdz, ən ðeɪ wəd pɹɑbli ɹʌn əz sun əz ðeɪ sɔ ə tʃɹɑlɑk. "ɪf oʊnli wi nu haʊ mɛni tʃɹɑləks feɪn hæz, ən haʊ mɛni dɑɹkfɹɛnz. juv kʌɾ ɪz nʌmbɝz daʊn." hi dɪd nɑt mɛnʃən ðə tʃɹɑlɑk i hæd kɪld, bʌt fɹəm ɪz fɹaʊn, hɪz lɔŋ aɪbɹaʊz hæŋɪŋ daʊn ɑntu hɪz tʃiks, hi wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv ɪt.

Loial began ticking off points on his thick fingers. "Fain is out there, or there would not have been Trollocs in the Foregate. If we ride out, they will be on us as soon as we are out of sight of the city. If we travel with a merchant train, they'll certainly attack it." No merchant would have more than five or six guards, and they would probably run as soon as they saw a Trolloc. "If only we knew how many Trollocs Fain has, and how many Darkfriends. You have cut his numbers down." He did not mention the Trolloc he had killed, but from his frown, his long eyebrows hanging down onto his cheeks, he was thinking of it.

"ɪt dʌzn mæɾɝ haʊ mɛni hi hæz," ɹænd sɛd. "tɛn ɑɹ əz bæɾ əz ə hʌnʒɹəd. ɪf tɛn tʃɹɑləks ətæk ʌs, aɪ doʊn θɪŋk wɪl ɡɛɾ əweɪ əɡɛn." hi əvɔɪɾəd θɪŋkɪŋ ə ðə weɪ hi maɪt, dʒʌs maɪt, dil wɪð tɛn tʃɹɑləks. ɪt hæd nɑt wɝkt wən i tʃɹaɪd tə hɛlp lɔɪəl, æftɝ ɔl.

"It doesn't matter how many he has," Rand said. "Ten are as bad as a hundred. If ten Trollocs attack us, I don't think we'll get away again." He avoided thinking of the way he might, just might, deal with ten Trollocs. It had not worked when he tried to help Loial, after all.

"aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk wi kʊd, iðɝ. aɪ doʊn θɪŋk wɪv mʌni tə teɪk pæsədʒ vɛɹi fɑɹ, bʌɾ ivən soʊ, ɪf wi tʃɹaɪd tə ɹitʃ ðə fɔɹɡeɪt dɑks - wɛl, feɪn mʌst əv dɑɹkfɹɛnz wɑtʃɪŋ. ɪf i θɔt wi wɝ teɪkɪŋ ʃɪp, aɪ doʊn bɪliv i wəd kɛɹ u sɔ ðə tʃɹɑləks. ivən ɪf wi fɔt fɹi ʌv əm sʌmhaʊ, wi wəɾ əv tə ɪkspleɪn aʊɝsɛlvz tə ðə sɪɾi ɡɑɹdz, ən ðeɪ wəd sɝɾənli nɑt bɪliv wi kænɑɾ oʊpən ðə tʃɛst, soʊ - "

"I do not think we could, either. I don't think we have money to take passage very far, but even so, if we tried to reach the Foregate docks - well, Fain must have Darkfriends watching. If he thought we were taking ship, I don't believe he would care who saw the Trollocs. Even if we fought free of them somehow, we would have to explain ourselves to the city guards, and they would certainly not believe we cannot open the chest, so - "

"wi ɑɹ nɑt lɛɾɪŋ ɛni kɛɹhinɪn si ðət tʃɛst, lɔɪəl."

"We are not letting any Cairhienin see that chest, Loial."

ði oʊɡiɝ nɑɾəd. "æn ðə sɪɾi dɑks ɑɹ noʊ ɡʊd, iðɝ." ðə sɪɾi dɑks wɝ ɹɪzɝv fəɹ ðə ɡɹeɪn bɑɹdʒəz ən ðə plɛʒɝ kɹæft ə ðə lɔɹdz ən leɪɾiz. noʊ wʌn keɪm tə ðɛm wɪθaʊt pɝmɪʃən. wʌn kəd lʊk daʊn ɑn əm fɹəm ðə wɔl, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ə dʒɹɑp ðət wəd bɹeɪk ivən lɔɪəlz nɛk. lɔɪəl wɪɡɡəld ɪz θʌm əz ɪf tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə θɪŋk ʌv ə pɔɪn fəɹ ðæt, tu. "aɪ səpoʊz ɪts tu bæd wi kænɑt ɹitʃ stɛɾɪŋ tsəfu. tʃɹɑləks wəd nɛvɝ kʌm ɪndə ə stɛɾɪŋ. bʌɾ aɪ doʊn səpoʊz ðeɪ wəd lɛɾ əs ɡɛt ðət fɑɹ wɪθaʊɾ ətækɪŋ."

The Ogier nodded. "And the city docks are no good, either." The city docks were reserved for the grain barges and the pleasure craft of the lords and ladies. No one came to them without permission. One could look down on them from the wall, but it was a drop that would break even Loial's neck. Loial wiggled his thumb as if trying to think of a point for that, too. "I suppose it is too bad we cannot reach Stedding Tsofu. Trollocs would never come into a stedding. But I don't suppose they would let us get that far without attacking."

ɹænd dɪd nɑɾ ænsɝ. ðeɪ hæd ɹitʃt ðə bɪɡ ɡɑɹdhaʊs dʒʌst ɪnsaɪd ðə ɡeɪt baɪ wɪtʃ ðeɪ hæd fɝst ɛntɝd kɛɹhin. aʊtsaɪd, ðə fɔɹɡeɪt timd ən mɪld, ən ə pɛɹ ʌv ɡɑɹdz kɛpt wɑtʃ ɑn ðɛm. ɹænd θɔɾ ə mæn, dʒɹɛst ɪn wʌt hæd wʌns bɪn ɡʊd ʃaɪnɝən kloʊðz, dʌk bæk ɪndə ðə kɹaʊɾ ət ðə saɪɾ ə hɪm, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt bi ʃʊɹ. ðəɹ wɝ tu mɛni pipəl ɪn kloʊðz fɹəm tu mɛni lænz, ɔl ə ðɛm hɝiɪŋ. hi wɛn ʌp ðə stɛps ɪndə ðə ɡɑɹdhaʊs, pæs bɹɛstpleɪɾɪd ɡɑɹdz ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə dɔɹ.

Rand did not answer. They had reached the big guardhouse just inside the gate by which they had first entered Cairhien. Outside, the Foregate teemed and milled, and a pair of guards kept watch on them. Rand thought a man, dressed in what had once been good Shienaran clothes, ducked back into the crowd at the sight of him, but he could not be sure. There were too many people in clothes from too many lands, all of them hurrying. He went up the steps into the guardhouse, past breastplated guards on either side of the door.

ðə lɑɹdʒ æntəɹum hæd hɑɹd wʊɾən bɛntʃɪz fəɹ pipəl wɪð bɪznəs ðɛɹ, meɪnli foʊk weɪɾɪŋ wɪð ə hʌmbəl peɪʃəns, wɛɹɪŋ ðə pleɪn, dɑɹk ɡɑɹməns ðət mɑɹk ðə pʊɹɝ kɑmənɝz. ðəɹ wɝ ə fju fɔɹɡeɪɾɝz əmʌŋ ðɛm, pɪkt aʊt baɪ ʃæbaɪnəs ən bɹaɪt kʌlɝz, noʊ daʊt hoʊpɪŋ fəɹ pɝmɪʃən tə sik wɝk ɪnsaɪd ðə wɔlz.

The large anteroom had hard wooden benches for people with business there, mainly folk waiting with a humble patience, wearing the plain, dark garments that marked the poorer commoners. There were a few Foregaters among them, picked out by shabbiness and bright colors, no doubt hoping for permission to seek work inside the walls.

ɹænd wɛn stʃɹeɪt tə ðə lɔŋ teɪbəl ɪn ðə bæk ə ðə ɹum. ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli wʌn mæn siɾəd bɪhaɪn ɪt, nɑɾ ə soʊlʒɝ, wɪð wʌn ɡɹin bɑɹ əkɹɔs ɪz koʊt. ə plʌmp fɛloʊ huz skɪn lʊk tu taɪt, hi ədʒʌstəd dɑkjəməns ɑn ðə teɪbəl ən ʃɪftəd ðə pəzɪʃən ə hɪz ɪŋkwɛl twaɪs bɪfɔɹ lʊkɪŋ ʌp ət ɹænd ən lɔɪəl wɪð ə fɔls smaɪl.

Rand went straight to the long table in the back of the room. There was only one man seated behind it, not a soldier, with one green bar across his coat. A plump fellow whose skin looked too tight, he adjusted documents on the table and shifted the position of his inkwell twice before looking up at Rand and Loial with a false smile.

"haʊ meɪ aɪ hɛlp ju, maɪ lɔɹd?"

"How may I help you, my Lord?"

"ðə seɪm weɪ aɪ hoʊp jə kəd hɛlp mi jɛstɝdeɪ," ɹænd sɛd wɪð mɔɹ peɪʃəns ðən i fɛlt, "æn ðə deɪ bɪfɔɹ, ən ðə deɪ bɪfɔɹ ðæt. hæz lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹ kʌm?"

"The same way I hoped you could help me yesterday," Rand said with more patience than he felt, "and the day before, and the day before that. Has Lord Ingtar come?"

"lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹ, maɪ lɔɹd?"

"Lord Ingtar, my Lord?"

ɹænd tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ ən lɛɾ ɪɾ aʊt sloʊli. "lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹ ə haʊs ʃɪnoʊwə, fɹəm ʃaɪnɝ. ðə seɪm mæn aɪ hæv æskt æftɝ ɛvɹi deɪ aɪv kʌm hɪɹ."

Rand took a deep breath and let it out slowly. "Lord Ingtar of House Shinowa, from Shienar. The same man I have asked after every day I've come here."

"noʊ wʌn ə ðət neɪm əz ɛntɝd ðə sɪɾi, maɪ lɔɹd."

"No one of that name has entered the city, my Lord."

"ɑɹ jə sɝɾən? doʊn jə nid tə lʊk ət jəɹ lɪsts, ət list?"

"Are you certain? Don't you need to look at your lists, at least?"

"maɪ lɔɹd, ðə lɪsts ə fɔɹənɝz u hæv kʌm tə kɛɹhin ɑɹ ɪkstʃeɪnʒd əmʌŋ ðə ɡɑɹdhaʊsɪz ət sʌnɹaɪz ən ət sʌnsɛt, ən aɪ ɪɡzæmɪn əm əz sun əz ðeɪ kʌm bɪfɔɹ mi. noʊ ʃaɪnɝən lɔɹɾ əz ɛntɝd kɛɹhin ɪn səm taɪm."

"My Lord, the lists of foreigners who have come to Cairhien are exchanged among the guardhouses at sunrise and at sunset, and I examine them as soon as they come before me. No Shienaran lord has entered Cairhien in some time."

"æn ðə leɪɾi səlin? bɪfɔɹ jə æsk əɡɛn, aɪ də nɑt noʊ hɝ haʊs. bʌɾ aɪv ɡɪvən jə hɝ neɪm, ən aɪ hæv dɪskɹaɪbd əɹ tə jə θɹi taɪmz. ɪzən ðəɾ ɪnʌf?"

"And the Lady Selene? Before you ask again, I do not know her House. But I've given you her name, and I have described her to you three times. Isn't that enough?"

ðə mæn spɹɛɾ ɪz hænz. "aɪ æm sɑɹi, maɪ lɔɹd. nɑt noʊɪŋ əɹ haʊs meɪks ɪt vɛɹi dɪfəkəlt." hi hæɾ ə blæn lʊk ɑn ɪz feɪs. ɹænd wʌndɝd wɛðɝ i wəd tɛl ivən ɪf i nu.

The man spread his hands. "I am sorry, my Lord. Not knowing her House makes it very difficult." He had a bland look on his face. Rand wondered whether he would tell even if he knew.

ə muvmən ət wʌn ə ðə dɔɹz bɪhaɪn ðə dɛsk kɑt ɹændz aɪ - ə mæn stɑɹɾɪŋ tə stɛp ɪndə ði æntəɹum, ðən tɝnɪŋ əweɪ hɝidli. "pɝhæps kæptən kɔldɛvwɪn kən hɛlp mi," ɹænd toʊl ðə klɝk.

A movement at one of the doors behind the desk caught Rand's eye - a man starting to step into the anteroom, then turning away hurriedly. "Perhaps Captain Caldevwin can help me," Rand told the clerk.

"kæptən kɔldɛvwɪn, maɪ lɔɹd?"

"Captain Caldevwin, my Lord?"

"aɪ dʒʌst sɔ hɪm bɪhaɪn ju."

"I just saw him behind you."

"aɪ æm sɑɹi, maɪ lɔɹd. ɪf ðəɹ wɑz ə kæptən kɔldɛvwɪn ɪn ðə ɡɑɹdhaʊs, aɪ wəd noʊ."

"I am sorry, my Lord. If there was a Captain Caldevwin in the guardhouse, I would know."

ɹænd stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪm əntɪl lɔɪəl tʌtʃt ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. "ɹænd, aɪ θɪŋk wi maɪɾ əz wɛl ɡoʊ."

Rand stared at him until Loial touched his shoulder. "Rand, I think we might as well go."

"θæŋk jə fəɹ jəɹ hɛlp," ɹænd sɛɾ ɪn ə taɪt vɔɪs. "aɪ wɪl ɹɪtɝn təmɑɹoʊ."

"Thank you for your help," Rand said in a tight voice. "I will return tomorrow."

"ɪɾ ɪz maɪ plɛʒɝ tə də wʌɾ aɪ meɪ," ðə mæn sɛd wɪð ɪz fɔls smaɪl.

"It is my pleasure to do what I may," the man said with his false smile.

ɹænd stɔkt aʊɾ ə ðə ɡɑɹdhaʊs soʊ fæs ðət lɔɪəl hæd tə hɝi tə kætʃ ɪm ʌp ɪn ðə stʃɹit. "hi wɑz laɪɪŋ, jə noʊ, lɔɪəl." hi dɪd nɑt sloʊ daʊn, bʌt ɹæðɝ hɝiɾ əlɔŋ əz ɪf i kəd bɝn əweɪ səm ə hɪz fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən θɹu fɪzɪkəl ɪɡzɝʃən. "kɔldɛvwɪn wɑz ðɛɹ. hi kəd bi laɪɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɔl ʌv ɪt. ɪŋtʃɹ kəɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bi hɪɹ, lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ʌs. əl bɛɾ i noʊz u səlin ɪz, tu."

Rand stalked out of the guardhouse so fast that Loial had to hurry to catch him up in the street. "He was lying, you know, Loial." He did not slow down, but rather hurried along as if he could burn away some of his frustration through physical exertion. "Caldevwin was there. He could be lying about all of it. Ingtar could already be here, looking for us. I'll bet he knows who Selene is, too."

"pɝhæps, ɹænd. deɪz deɪmɑɹ - "

"Perhaps, Rand. Daes Dae'mar - "

"laɪt, aɪm taɪɝɾ ə hɪɹɪŋ əbaʊt ðə ɡɹeɪt ɡeɪm. aɪ doʊnt wɑnə pleɪ ɪt. aɪ də nɑt wɑnə bi ɛni pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt." lɔɪəl wɔk bɪsaɪd hɪm, seɪɪŋ nʌθɪŋ. "aɪ noʊ," ɹænd sɛɾ ət læst. "ðeɪ θɪŋk ɪm ə lɔɹd, ən ɪn kɛɹhin, ivən aʊtlæn lɔɹdz ɑɹ pɑɹɾ ə ðə ɡeɪm. aɪ wɪʃ aɪd nɛvɝ pʊɾ ɑn ðɪs koʊt." mɔɪɹeɪn, hi θɔt bɪɾɝli. ʃiz stɪl kɑzɪŋ mi tʃɹʌbəl. ɔlmoʊst ɪmiɾiətli, ðoʊ, ɪf ɹɪlʌktənli, hi ədmɪɾəd ðət ʃi kəd hɑɹdli bi bleɪm fəɹ ðɪs. ðəɹ hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn səm ɹizən tə pɹitɛn tə bi wʌɾ i wɑz nɑt. fɝs kipɪŋ hʊɹɪnz spɪɹəts ʌp, ən ðən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɪmpɹɛs səlin. æftɝ səlin, ðəɹ hæd nɑt sim tə bi ɛni weɪ aʊɾ ʌv ɪt. hɪz stɛps sloʊɾ əntɪl i keɪm tə ə hɔlt. "wɛn mɔɪɹeɪn lemi ɡoʊ, aɪ θɔt θɪŋz wəd bi sɪmpəl əɡɛn. ivən tʃeɪsɪŋ æftɝ ðə hɔɹn, ivən wɪð - wɪð ɛvɹiθɪŋ, aɪ θɔɾ ɪt wəd bi sɪmpəl." ivən wɪð seɪɾɪn ɪnsaɪd jəɹ hɛd? "laɪt, wʌɾ aɪ wʊdnt ɡɪv tə hæv ɛvɹiθɪŋ bi sɪmpəl əɡɛn."

"Light, I'm tired of hearing about the Great Game. I don't want to play it. I do not want to be any part of it." Loial walked beside him, saying nothing. "I know," Rand said at last. "They think I'm a lord, and in Cairhien, even outland lords are part of the Game. I wish I'd never put on this coat." Moiraine, he thought bitterly. She's still causing me trouble. Almost immediately, though, if reluctantly, he admitted that she could hardly be blamed for this. There had always been some reason to pretend to be what he was not. First keeping Hurin's spirits up, and then trying to impress Selene. After Selene, there had not seemed to be any way out of it. His steps slowed until he came to a halt. "When Moiraine let me go, I thought things would be simple again. Even chasing after the Horn, even with - with everything, I thought it would be simple." Even with saidin inside your head? "Light, what I wouldn't give to have everything be simple again."

"tɑvɝən," lɔɪəl bɪɡæn.

"Ta'veren," Loial began.

"aɪ də nɑt wɑnə hɪɹ əbaʊt ðæt, iðɝ." ɹænd stɑɹɾəd ɔf əɡɛn əz fæst əz bɪfɔɹ. "ɔl aɪ wɑn ɪz tə ɡɪv ðə dæɡɝ tə mæt, ən ðə hɔɹn tə ɪŋtʃɹ." ðən wʌt? ɡoʊ mæd? daɪ? ɪf aɪ daɪ bɪfɔɹ aɪ ɡoʊ mæd, ət list aɪ woʊn hɝɾ ɛnibəɾi ɛls. bʌɾ aɪ doʊnt wɑnə daɪ, iðɝ. læn kən tɔk əbaʊt ʃiðɪŋ ðə sɔɹd, bʌɾ ɪm ə ʃɛpɝd, nɑɾ ə wɔɹɾɝ. "ɪf aɪ kən dʒʌs nɑt tʌtʃ ɪt," hi mʌɾɝd, "meɪbi aɪ kæn. . . . oʊɪn ɔlmoʊs meɪɾ ɪt."

"I do not want to hear about that, either." Rand started off again as fast as before. "All I want is to give the dagger to Mat, and the Horn to Ingtar." Then what? Go mad? Die? If I die before I go mad, at least I won't hurt anybody else. But I don't want to die, either. Lan can talk about Sheathing the Sword, but I'm a shepherd, not a Warder. "If I can just not touch it," he muttered, "maybe I can. . . . Owyn almost made it."

"wʌt, ɹænd? aɪ dɪdn hɪɹ ðæt."

"What, Rand? I didn't hear that."

"ɪt wɑz nʌθɪŋ," ɹænd sɛd wɛɹəli. "aɪ wɪʃ ɪŋtʃɹ wəd ɡɛt hɪɹ. ən mæt, ən pɛɹɪn."

"It was nothing," Rand said wearily. "I wish Ingtar would get here. And Mat, and Perrin."

ðeɪ wɔkt əlɔŋ ɪn saɪləns fəɹ ə taɪm, wɪð ɹænd lɔst ɪn θɔt. tɑmz nɛfju hæd læstəɾ ɔlmoʊs θɹi jɪɹz baɪ tʃænəlɪŋ oʊnli wən i θɔɾ i hæd tə. ɪf oʊɪn hæd mænədʒ tə lɪmət haʊ ɔfən i tʃænəld, ɪt mʌs bi pɑsəbəl tə nɑt tʃænəl əɾ ɔl, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ sɪdʌktɪv seɪɾɪn wɑz.

They walked along in silence for a time, with Rand lost in thought. Thom's nephew had lasted almost three years by channeling only when he thought he had to. If Owyn had managed to limit how often he channeled, it must be possible to not channel at all, no matter how seductive saidin was.

"ɹænd," lɔɪəl sɛd, "ðɛɹz ə faɪɝ ʌp əhɛd."

"Rand," Loial said, "there's a fire up ahead."

ɹænd ɡɑt ɹɪɾ ə hɪz ənwɛlkəm θɔts ən lʊkt ɔf ɪndə ðə sɪɾi, fɹaʊnɪŋ. ə θɪk kɑləm ə blæk smoʊk bɪloʊɾ ʌp əbʌv ðə ɹuftɑps. hi kəd nɑt si wʌt leɪ ət ðə beɪs ʌv ɪt, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz tu kloʊz tə ði ɪn.

Rand got rid of his unwelcome thoughts and looked off into the city, frowning. A thick column of black smoke billowed up above the rooftops. He could not see what lay at the base of it, but it was too close to the inn.

"dɑɹkfɹɛnz," hi sɛd, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə smoʊk. "tʃɹɑləks kæn kʌm ɪnsaɪd ðə wɔlz wɪθaʊt biɪŋ sin, bʌt dɑɹkfɹɛnz. . . . hʊɹɪn!" hi bɹoʊk ɪndə ə ɹʌn, lɔɪəl izəli kipɪŋ peɪs bɪsaɪd hɪm.

"Darkfriends," he said, staring at the smoke. "Trollocs can't come inside the walls without being seen, but Darkfriends. . . . Hurin!" He broke into a run, Loial easily keeping pace beside him.

ðə kloʊsɝ ðeɪ keɪm, ðə mɔɹ sɝɾən ɪt wɑz, əntɪl ðeɪ ɹaʊndəd ðə læst stoʊn-tɛɹəs kɔɹnɝ ən ðəɹ wɑz ðə dɪfɛndɝ ə ðə dʒɹæɡoʊnwɔl, smoʊk pɔɹɪŋ aʊɾ ʌv ɪts ʌpɝ wɪndoʊz ən fleɪmz bɹeɪkɪŋ θɹu ðə ɹuf. ə kɹaʊd hæd ɡæðɝɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ði ɪn. kueɪli, ʃaʊɾɪŋ ən dʒʌmpɪŋ əbaʊt, wɑz dɝɛktɪŋ mɛn kæɹiɪŋ fɝnɪʃɪŋz aʊɾ ɪndə ðə stʃɹit. ə dʌbəl laɪn ə mɛn pæst ɪnsaɪd bʌkəts fɪld wɪð wɔɾɝ fɹəm ə wɛl daʊn ðə stʃɹiɾ ən ɛmpti bʌkəts bæk aʊt. moʊst ə ðə pipəl oʊnli stʊɾ ən wɑtʃt; ə nu ɡaʊɾ ə fleɪm bɝs θɹu ðə sleɪt ɹuf, ən ðeɪ ɡeɪv ə laʊɾ ɑə.

The closer they came, the more certain it was, until they rounded the last stone-terraced corner and there was The Defender of the Dragonwall, smoke pouring out of its upper windows and flames breaking through the roof. A crowd had gathered in front of the inn. Cuale, shouting and jumping about, was directing men carrying furnishings out into the street. A double line of men passed inside buckets filled with water from a well down the street and empty buckets back out. Most of the people only stood and watched; a new gout of flame burst through the slate roof, and they gave a loud aaaah.

ɹænd pʊʃt θɹu ðə kɹaʊd tə ði ɪnkipɝ. "wɛɹ ɪz hʊɹɪn?"

Rand pushed through the crowd to the innkeeper. "Where is Hurin?"

"kɛɹfəl wɪð ðət teɪbəl!" kueɪli ʃaʊɾəd. "du nɑt skɹeɪp ɪt!" hi lʊkt ət ɹænd ən blɪŋkt. hɪz feɪs wɑz smʌdʒd wɪð smoʊk. "maɪ lɔɹd? hu? jəɹ mænsɝvənt? aɪ də nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ siɪŋ hɪm, maɪ lɔɹd. noʊ daʊɾ i wɛn aʊt. də nɑt dʒɹɑp ðoʊz kændəlstɪks, ful! ðeɪ ɑɹ sɪlvɝ!" kueɪli dænst ɔf tə hɝæŋ ðə mɛn lʌɡɪŋ ɪz bɪlɔŋɪŋz aʊɾ ə ði ɪn.

"Careful with that table!" Cuale shouted. "Do not scrape it!" He looked at Rand and blinked. His face was smudged with smoke. "My Lord? Who? Your manservant? I do not remember seeing him, my Lord. No doubt he went out. Do not drop those candlesticks, fool! They are silver!" Cuale danced off to harangue the men lugging his belongings out of the inn.

"hʊɹɪn wʊdn əv ɡɔn aʊt," lɔɪəl sɛd. "hi wəd nɑɾ əv lɛf ðə. . . ." hi lʊkt ɝaʊn ən lɛft ɪɾ ənsɛd; səm ə ði ɔnlʊkɝz sim tə faɪn ən oʊɡiɝ əz ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ əz ðə faɪɝ.

"Hurin wouldn't have gone out," Loial said. "He would not have left the. . . ." He looked around and left it unsaid; some of the onlookers seemed to find an Ogier as interesting as the fire.

"aɪ noʊ," ɹænd sɛd, ən plʌnʒd ɪndə ði ɪn.

"I know," Rand said, and plunged into the inn.

ðə kɑmən ɹum hɑɹdli simd əz ɪf ðə bɪldɪŋ wɝ ɑn faɪɝ. ðə dʌbəl laɪn ə mɛn stʃɹɛtʃt ʌp ðə stɛɹz, pæsɪŋ ðɛɹ bʌkəts, ən ʌðɝz skɹæmbəl tə kæɹi aʊt wʌt fɝnɪtʃɝ wɑz lɛft, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ mɔɹ smoʊk daʊn hɪɹ ðən ɪf sʌmθɪŋ hæd bɪn bɝnɪŋ ðə kɪtʃən. əz ɹænd pɹɛst əpstɛɹz, ɪt bɪɡæn tə θɪkən. kɑfɪŋ, hi ɹæn ʌp ðə stɛps.

The common room hardly seemed as if the building were on fire. The double line of men stretched up the stairs, passing their buckets, and others scrambled to carry out what furniture was left, but there was no more smoke down here than if something had been burning the kitchen. As Rand pressed upstairs, it began to thicken. Coughing, he ran up the steps.

ðə laɪnz stɑpt ʃɔɹɾ ə ðə sɛkən lændɪŋ, mɛn hæfweɪ ʌp ðə stɛɹz hɝlɪŋ ðɛɹ wɔɾɝ ʌp ɪndə ə smoʊk-fɪl hɔlweɪ. fleɪmz lɪkɪŋ ʌp ðə wɔlz flɪkɝd ɹɛd θɹu ðə blæk smoʊk.

The lines stopped short of the second landing, men halfway up the stairs hurling their water up into a smoke-filled hallway. Flames licking up the walls flickered red through the black smoke.

wʌn ə ðə mɛn ɡɹæbd ɹændz ɑɹm. "ju kænɑt ɡoʊ ʌp ðɛɹ, maɪ lɔɹd. ɪts ɔl lɔst əbʌv hɪɹ. oʊɡiɝ, spik tə hɪm."

One of the men grabbed Rand's arm. "You cannot go up there, my Lord. It is all lost above here. Ogier, speak to him."

ɪt wɑz ðə fɝst ɹænd ɹilaɪz ðət lɔɪəl hæd fɑloʊd hɪm. "ɡoʊ bæk, lɔɪəl. əl bɹɪŋ ɪm aʊt."

It was the first Rand realized that Loial had followed him. "Go back, Loial. I'll bring him out."

"ju kænɑt kæɹi hʊɹɪn ən ðə tʃɛs boʊθ, ɹænd." ði oʊɡiɝ ʃɹʌɡd. "bɪsaɪdz, aɪ woʊn liv maɪ bʊks tə bɝn."

"You cannot carry Hurin and the chest both, Rand." The Ogier shrugged. "Besides, I won't leave my books to burn."

"ðɛn kip loʊ. ʌndɝ ðə smoʊk." ɹænd dʒɹɑp tə hɪz hænz ən niz ɑn ðə stɛɹz, ən skɹæmbəld ʌp ðə ɹɛst ə ðə weɪ. ðəɹ wɑz klinɝ ɛɹ daʊn nɪɹ ðə flɔɹ; stɪl smoʊki ɪnʌf tə meɪk ɪm kɑf, bʌɾ i kəd bɹið ɪt. jɛɾ ivən ði ɛɹ sim blɪstɝɪŋ hɑt. hi kəd nɑt ɡɛɾ ɪnʌf ʌv ɪt θɹu hɪz noʊz. hi bɹið θɹu hɪz maʊθ, ən fɛlt ɪz tʌŋ dʒɹaɪɪŋ.

"Then keep low. Under the smoke." Rand dropped to his hands and knees on the stairs, and scrambled up the rest of the way. There was cleaner air down near the floor; still smoky enough to make him cough, but he could breathe it. Yet even the air seemed blistering hot. He could not get enough of it through his nose. He breathed through his mouth, and felt his tongue drying.

səm ə ðə wɔɾɝ ðə mɛn θɹu lændəɾ ɑn hɪm, soʊkɪŋ ɪm tə ðə skɪn. ðə kulnəs wɑz oʊnli ə moʊməntɛɹi ɹɪlif; ðə hit keɪm ɹaɪt bæk. hi kɹɔld ɑn dətɝmənədli, əwɛɹ ə lɔɪəl bɪhaɪn ɪm oʊnli fɹəm ði oʊɡiɝz kɑfɪŋ.

Some of the water the men threw landed on him, soaking him to the skin. The coolness was only a momentary relief; the heat came right back. He crawled on determinedly, aware of Loial behind him only from the Ogier's coughing.

wʌn wɔl ə ðə hɔlweɪ wɑz ɔlmoʊst sɑləd fleɪm, ən ðə flɔɹ nɪɹ ɪt hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bɪɡʌn tə æd θɪn tɛnʒɹəlz tə ðə klaʊd ðət hʌŋ oʊvɝ ɪz hɛd. hi wɑz ɡlæɾ i kəd nɑt si wʌt leɪ əbʌv ðə smoʊk. ɑmənəs kɹæklɪŋ toʊld ɪnʌf.

One wall of the hallway was almost solid flame, and the floor near it had already begun to add thin tendrils to the cloud that hung over his head. He was glad he could not see what lay above the smoke. Ominous crackling told enough.

ðə dɔɹ tə hʊɹɪnz ɹum hæd nɑt kɑt jɛt, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz hɑɾ ɪnʌf ðəɾ i hæd tə tʃɹaɪ twaɪs bɪfɔɹ i kəd mænədʒ tə pʊʃ ɪɾ oʊpən. ðə fɝs θɪŋ tə miɾ ɪz aɪ wɑz hʊɹɪn, spɹɔld ɑn ðə flɔɹ. ɹænd kɹɔl tə ðə snɪfɝ ən lɪftəɾ ɪm ʌp. ðəɹ wɑz ə lʌmp ɑn ðə saɪɾ ə hɪz hɛd ðə saɪz ʌv ə plʌm.

The door to Hurin's room had not caught yet, but it was hot enough that he had to try twice before he could manage to push it open. The first thing to meet his eye was Hurin, sprawled on the floor. Rand crawled to the sniffer and lifted him up. There was a lump on the side of his head the size of a plum.

hʊɹɪn oʊpən ənfoʊkəst aɪz. "lɔɹd ɹænd?" hi mɝmɝd feɪnli. ". . . nɑk ət ðə dɔɹ . . . θɔɾ ɪt wɑz mɔɹ ɪnvi. . . ." hɪz aɪz ɹoʊl bæk ɪn ɪz hɛd. ɹænd fɛl fəɹ ə hɑɹtbit, ən sæɡd wɪð ɹɪlif wən i faʊn ɪt.

Hurin opened unfocused eyes. "Lord Rand?" he murmured faintly. ". . . knock at the door . . . thought it was more invi. . . ." His eyes rolled back in his head. Rand felt for a heartbeat, and sagged with relief when he found it.

"ɹænd. . . ." lɔɪəl kɔft. hi wɑz bɪsaɪɾ ɪz bɛd, wɪð ðə kʌvɝz θɹoʊn ʌp tə ɹɪvil ðə bɛɹ bɔɹdz ʌndɝniθ. ðə tʃɛst wɑz ɡɔn.

"Rand. . . ." Loial coughed. He was beside his bed, with the covers thrown up to reveal the bare boards underneath. The chest was gone.

əbʌv ðə smoʊk, ðə silɪŋ kɹikt, ən fleɪmɪŋ pisəz ʌv wʊd fɛl tə ðə flɔɹ.

Above the smoke, the ceiling creaked, and flaming pieces of wood fell to the floor.

ɹænd sɛd, "ɡɛt jəɹ bʊks. əl teɪk hʊɹɪn. hɝi." hi stɑɹɾəd tə dʒɹeɪp ðə lɪmp snɪfɝ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝz, bʌt lɔɪəl tʊk hʊɹɪn fɹəm hɪm.

Rand said, "Get your books. I will take Hurin. Hurry." He started to drape the limp sniffer over his shoulders, but Loial took Hurin from him.

"ðə bʊks wɪl əv tə bɝn, ɹænd. jə kæn kæɹi hɪm ən kɹɔl, ən ɪf jə stæn ʌp, jəl nɛvɝ ɹitʃ ðə stɛɹz." ði oʊɡiɝ pʊl hʊɹɪn ʌp ɑntu hɪz bɹɔd bæk, ɑɹmz ən lɛɡz hæŋɪŋ tə iðɝ saɪd. ðə silɪŋ ɡeɪv ə laʊd kɹæk. "wi mʌs hɝi, ɹænd."

"The books will have to burn, Rand. You can't carry him and crawl, and if you stand up, you will never reach the stairs." The Ogier pulled Hurin up onto his broad back, arms and legs hanging to either side. The ceiling gave a loud crack. "We must hurry, Rand."

"ɡoʊ, lɔɪəl. ɡoʊ, ən əl fɑloʊ."

"Go, Loial. Go, and I'll follow."

ði oʊɡiɝ kɹɔld ɪndə ðə hɔl wɪð ɪz bɝɾən, ən ɹænd stɑɹɾəd æftɝ hɪm. ðən i stɑpt, stɛɹɪŋ bæk ət ðə kənɛktɪŋ dɔɹ tə hɪz ɹum. ðə bænɝ wɑz stɪl ɪn ðɛɹ. ðə bænɝ ə ðə dʒɹæɡən. lɛɾ ɪt bɝn, hi θɔt, ən ən ænsɝɪŋ θɔt keɪm əz ɪf i hæd hɝd mɔɪɹeɪn seɪ ɪt. jəɹ laɪf meɪ dɪpɛn ɑn ɪt. ʃiz stɪl tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə juz mi. jəɹ laɪf meɪ dɪpɛn ɑn ɪt. ɛɛs sədaɪ nɛvɝ laɪ.

The Ogier crawled into the hall with his burden, and Rand started after him. Then he stopped, staring back at the connecting door to his room. The banner was still in there. The banner of the Dragon. Let it burn, he thought, and an answering thought came as if he had heard Moiraine say it. Your life may depend on it. She's still trying to use me. Your life may depend on it. Aes Sedai never lie.

wɪð ə ɡɹoʊn, hi ɹoʊld əkɹɔs ðə flɔɹ ən kɪkt oʊpən ðə dɔɹ tə hɪz ɹum.

With a groan, he rolled across the floor and kicked open the door to his room.

ði ʌðɝ ɹum wɑz ə mæs ə fleɪm. ðə bɛd wɑz ə bɑnfaɪɝ, ɹɛd ɹʌnɝz ɔlɹɛɾi kɹɔs ðə flɔɹ. ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ kɹɔlɪŋ əkɹɔs ðæt. ɡɛɾɪŋ tə hɪz fit, hi ɹæn kɹaʊtʃɪŋ ɪndə ðə ɹum, flɪntʃɪŋ fɹəm ðə hit, kɑfɪŋ, tʃoʊkɪŋ. stim ɹoʊz fɹəm ɪz dæmp koʊt. wʌn saɪɾ ə ðə wɔɹdʒɹoʊb wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi bɝnɪŋ. hi snætʃt oʊpən ðə dɔɹ. hɪz sæɾəlbæɡz leɪ ɪnsaɪd, stɪl pɹətɛktəd fɹəm ðə faɪɝ, wʌn saɪd bʌlʒɪŋ wɪð ðə bænɝ ə luz θɝɪn tɛləmən, ðə wʊɾən flut keɪs bɪsaɪd ðɛm. fəɹ ən ɪnstənt, hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. aɪ kəd stɪl lɛɾ ɪt bɝn.

The other room was a mass of flame. The bed was a bonfire, red runners already crossed the floor. There would be no crawling across that. Getting to his feet, he ran crouching into the room, flinching from the heat, coughing, choking. Steam rose from his damp coat. One side of the wardrobe was already burning. He snatched open the door. His saddlebags lay inside, still protected from the fire, one side bulging with the banner of Lews Therin Telamon, the wooden flute case beside them. For an instant, he hesitated. I could still let it burn.

ðə silɪŋ əbʌv ɪm ɡɹoʊnd. hi ɡɹæb sæɾəlbæɡz ən flut keɪs ən θɹu hɪmsɛlf bæk θɹu ðə dɔɹ, lændɪŋ ɑn ɪz niz əz bɝnɪŋ tɪmbɝz kɹæʃt wɛɹ i hæd stʊd. dʒɹæɡɪŋ ɪz bɝɾən, hi kɹɔld ɪndə ðə hɔl. ðə flɔɹ ʃʊk wɪð mɔɹ fɔlɪŋ bimz.

The ceiling above him groaned. He grabbed saddlebags and flute case and threw himself back through the door, landing on his knees as burning timbers crashed where he had stood. Dragging his burden, he crawled into the hall. The floor shook with more falling beams.

ðə mɛn wɪð ðə bʌkəts wɝ ɡɔn wən i ɹitʃt ðə stɛɹz. hi ɔl bʌt slɪd daʊn ðə stɛps tə ðə nɛks lændɪŋ, skɹæmbəl tə hɪz fiɾ ən ɹæn θɹu ðə naʊ-ɛmpti bɪldɪŋ ɪndə ðə stʃɹit. ði ɔnlʊkɝz stɛɹɾ ət hɪm, wɪð ɪz feɪs blækən ən ɪz koʊt kʌvɝd wɪð smʌt, bʌɾ i stæɡɝd tə wɛɹ lɔɪəl hæd pɹɑp hʊɹɪn əɡɛns ðə wɔl ʌv ə haʊs əkɹɔs ðə stʃɹit. ə wʊmən fɹəm ðə kɹaʊd wɑz waɪpɪŋ hʊɹɪnz feɪs wɪð ə klɔθ, bʌɾ ɪz aɪz wɝ stɪl kloʊzd, ən ɪz bɹɛθ keɪm ɪn hivz.

The men with the buckets were gone when he reached the stairs. He all but slid down the steps to the next landing, scrambled to his feet and ran through the now-empty building into the street. The onlookers stared at him, with his face blackened and his coat covered with smut, but he staggered to where Loial had propped Hurin against the wall of a house across the street. A woman from the crowd was wiping Hurin's face with a cloth, but his eyes were still closed, and his breath came in heaves.

"ɪz ðəɹ ə wɪzdəm nɪɹbaɪ?" ɹænd dɪmændəd. "hi nidz hɛlp." ðə wʊmən lʊkt əɾ ɪm blæŋkli, ən i tʃɹaɪd tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ði ʌðɝ neɪmz i hæd hɝd pipəl kɔl ðə wɪmən u wəd bi wɪsdəmz ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. "eɪ waɪz wʊmən? ə wʊmən jə kɔl mʌðɝ sʌmbɑɾi? ə wʊmən u noʊz ɝbz ən hilɪŋ?"

"Is there a Wisdom nearby?" Rand demanded. "He needs help." The woman looked at him blankly, and he tried to remember the other names he had heard people call the women who would be Wisdoms in the Two Rivers. "A Wise Woman? A woman you call Mother somebody? A woman who knows herbs and healing?"

"aɪ æm ə ɹiɾɝ, ɪf ðəɾ ɪz wʌt jə min," ðə wʊmən sɛd, "bʌɾ ɔl aɪ noʊ tə də fəɹ ðɪs wʌn ɪz tə meɪk ɪm kʌmftəɹbəl. sʌmθɪŋ ɪz bɹoʊkən ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz hɛd, aɪ fɪɹ."

"I am a Reader, if that is what you mean," the woman said, "but all I know to do for this one is to make him comfortable. Something is broken inside his head, I fear."

"ɹænd! ɪts ju!"

"Rand! It is you!"

ɹænd stɛɹd. ɪt wɑz mæt, liɾɪŋ ɪz hɔɹs θɹu ðə kɹaʊd, wɪð ɪz baʊ stʃɹʌŋ əkɹɔs ɪz bæk. eɪ mæt huz feɪs wɑz peɪl ən dʒɹɔn, bʌt stɪl mæt, ən ɡɹɪnɪŋ, ɪf wikli. ən bɪhaɪn ɪm keɪm pɛɹɪn, hɪz jɛloʊ aɪz ʃaɪnɪŋ ɪn ðə faɪɝ ən ɝnɪŋ əz mɛni lʊks əz ðə bleɪz. ən ɪŋtʃɹ, dɪsmaʊntɪŋ ɪn ə haɪ-kɑlɝd koʊɾ ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ɑɹmɝ, bʌt stɪl wɪð ɪz sɔɹd hɪl stɪkɪŋ ʌp oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ.

Rand stared. It was Mat, leading his horse through the crowd, with his bow strung across his back. A Mat whose face was pale and drawn, but still Mat, and grinning, if weakly. And behind him came Perrin, his yellow eyes shining in the fire and earning as many looks as the blaze. And Ingtar, dismounting in a high-collared coat instead of armor, but still with his sword hilt sticking up over his shoulder.

ɹænd fɛlt ə ʃɪvɝ ɹʌn θɹu hɪm. "ɪts tu leɪt," hi toʊl ðɛm. "ju keɪm tu leɪt." ən i sæt daʊn ɪn ðə stʃɹiɾ ən bɪɡæn tə læf.

Rand felt a shiver run through him. "It's too late," he told them. "You came too late." And he sat down in the street and began to laugh.


tʃæptɝ θɝɾiwʌn


CHAPTER 31

ɑn ðə sɛnt


On the Scent

ɹænd dɪd nɑt noʊ vɛɹɪn wɑz ðəɹ əntɪl ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tʊk ɪz feɪs ɪn əɹ hænz. fəɹ ə moʊmən i kəd si wɝi ɪn əɹ feɪs, pɝhæps ivən fɪɹ, ən ðən sʌɾənli hi fɛlt əz ɪf i hæd bɪn daʊst wɪð koʊld wɔɾɝ, nɑt ðə wɛt bʌt ðə tɪŋɡəl. hi ɡeɪv wʌn əbɹʌpt ʃʌɾɝ ən stɑp læfɪŋ; ʃi lɛft ɪm tə kɹaʊtʃ oʊvɝ hʊɹɪn. ðə ɹiɾɝ wɑtʃt əɹ kɛɹfəli. soʊ dɪd ɹænd. wʌɾ ɪz ʃi duɪŋ hɪɹ? əz ɪf aɪ dɪdnt noʊ.

Rand did not know Verin was there until the Aes Sedai took his face in her hands. For a moment he could see worry in her face, perhaps even fear, and then suddenly he felt as if he had been doused with cold water, not the wet but the tingle. He gave one abrupt shudder and stopped laughing; she left him to crouch over Hurin. The Reader watched her carefully. So did Rand. What is she doing here? As if I didn't know.

"wɛɹ dɪd jə ɡoʊ?" mæt dɪmændəd hɔɹsli. "ju ɔl dʒʌs dɪsəpɪɹd, ən naʊ jəɹ ɪn kɛɹhin əhɛɾ ʌv ʌs. lɔɪəl?" ði oʊɡiɝ ʃɹʌɡd ənsɝteɪnli ən aɪd ðə kɹaʊd, hɪz ɪɹz twɪtʃɪŋ. hæf ðə pipəl hæd tɝn fɹəm ðə faɪɝ tə wɑtʃ ðə nukʌmɝz. ə fju ɛdʒ kloʊsɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lɪsən.

"Where did you go?" Mat demanded hoarsely. "You all just disappeared, and now you're in Cairhien ahead of us. Loial?" The Ogier shrugged uncertainly and eyed the crowd, his ears twitching. Half the people had turned from the fire to watch the newcomers. A few edged closer trying to listen.

ɹænd lɛt pɛɹɪn ɡɪv ɪm ə hæn ʌp. "haʊ dɪd jə faɪn ði ɪn?" hi ɡlænst ət vɛɹɪn, nilɪŋ wɪð əɹ hænz ɑn ðə snɪfɝz hɛd. "hɝ?"

Rand let Perrin give him a hand up. "How did you find the inn?" He glanced at Verin, kneeling with her hands on the sniffer's head. "Her?"

"ɪn ə weɪ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ðə ɡɑɹdz ət ðə ɡeɪt wɑntəɾ əɹ neɪmz, ən ə fɛloʊ kʌmɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə ɡɑɹdhaʊs ɡeɪv ə dʒʌmp wən i hɝɾ ɪŋtʃɹz neɪm. hi sɛɾ i dɪdnt noʊ ɪt, bʌɾ i hæɾ ə smaɪl ðət ʃaʊɾəd 'laɪ' ə maɪl ɔf."

"In a way," Perrin said. "The guards at the gate wanted our names, and a fellow coming out of the guardhouse gave a jump when he heard Ingtar's name. He said he didn't know it, but he had a smile that shouted 'lie' a mile off."

"aɪ θɪŋk aɪ noʊ ðə mæn jə min," ɹænd sɛd. "hi smaɪlz ðət weɪ ɔl ðə taɪm."

"I think I know the man you mean," Rand said. "He smiles that way all the time."

"vɛɹɪn ʃoʊɾ ɪm əɹ ɹɪŋ," mæt pʊɾ ɪn, "ænd wɪspɝɾ ɪn ɪz ɪɹ." hi lʊkt ən saʊndəd sɪk, hɪz tʃiks flʌʃt ən taɪt, bʌɾ i mænədʒd ə ɡɹɪn. ɹænd hæd nɛvɝ noʊɾəst ɪz tʃikboʊnz bɪfɔɹ. "aɪ kʊdn hɪɹ wʌt ʃi sɛd, bʌɾ aɪ dɪdnt noʊ wɛðɝ ɪz aɪz wɝ gɑnə pɑp aʊɾ ə hɪz hɛɾ əɹ i wɑz gɑnə swɑloʊ hɪz tʌŋ fɝst. ɔl ʌv ə sʌɾən, hi kʊdn də ɪnʌf fəɹ ʌs. hi toʊld əs jə wɝ weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ʌs, ən ɹaɪt wɛɹ jə wɝ steɪɪŋ. ɔfɝd tə ɡaɪɾ əs hɪmsɛlf, bʌɾ i ɹɪli lʊkt ɹɪlivd wən vɛɹɪn toʊld ɪm noʊ." hi snɔɹɾɪd. "lɔɹd ɹænd ə haʊs ælθɹ."

"Verin showed him her ring," Mat put in, "and whispered in his ear." He looked and sounded sick, his cheeks flushed and tight, but he managed a grin. Rand had never noticed his cheekbones before. "I couldn't hear what she said, but I didn't know whether his eyes were going to pop out of his head or he was going to swallow his tongue first. All of a sudden, he couldn't do enough for us. He told us you were waiting for us, and right where you were staying. Offered to guide us himself, but he really looked relieved when Verin told him no." He snorted. "Lord Rand of House al'Thor."

"ɪts tu lɔŋ ə stɔɹi tə ɪkspleɪn naʊ," ɹænd sɛd. "wɛɹ ɑɹ ənoʊ ən ðə ɹɛst? wɪl nid ðɛm."

"It's too long a story to explain now," Rand said. "Where are Uno and the rest? We will need them."

"ɪn ðə fɔɹɡeɪt." mæt fɹaʊn ət hɪm, ən wɛn ɑn sloʊli, "ənoʊ sɛd ðeɪd ɹæðɝ steɪ ðəɹ ðən ɪnsaɪd ðə wɔlz. fɹəm wʌɾ aɪ kən si, aɪd ɹæðɝ bi wɪð ðɛm. ɹænd, waɪ wɪl wi niɾ ənoʊ? hæv jə faʊnd . . . ðɛm?"

"In the Foregate." Mat frowned at him, and went on slowly, "Uno said they'd rather stay there than inside the walls. From what I can see, I'd rather be with them. Rand, why will we need Uno? Have you found . . . them?"

ɪt wɑz ðə moʊmən ɹænd ɹilaɪz sʌɾənli hi hæd bɪn əvɔɪɾɪŋ. hi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ ən lʊkt ɪz fɹɛn ɪn ði aɪ. "mæt, aɪ hæd ðə dæɡɝ, ən aɪ lɔst ɪt. ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz tʊk ɪt bæk." hi hɝd ɡæsps fɹəm ðə kɛɹhinɪn lɪsnɪŋ, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt kɛɹ. ðeɪ kəd pleɪ ðɛɹ ɡɹeɪt ɡeɪm ɪf ðeɪ wɑntəd, bʌɾ ɪŋtʃɹ hæd kʌm, ən i wɑz fɪnɪʃt wɪð ɪɾ ət læst. "ðeɪ kæn əv ɡɔn fɑɹ, ðoʊ."

It was the moment Rand realized suddenly he had been avoiding. He took a deep breath and looked his friend in the eye. "Mat, I had the dagger, and I lost it. The Darkfriends took it back." He heard gasps from the Cairhienin listening, but he did not care. They could play their Great Game if they wanted, but Ingtar had come, and he was finished with it at last. "They can't have gone far, though."

ɪŋtʃɹ hæd bɪn saɪlənt, bʌt naʊ hi stɛp fɔɹwɝɾ ən ɡɹɪpt ɹændz ɑɹm. "ju hæɾ ɪt? ən ðə" - hi lʊkt ɝaʊn ət ði ɔnlʊkɝz - "ði ʌðɝ θɪŋ?"

Ingtar had been silent, but now he stepped forward and gripped Rand's arm. "You had it? And the" - he looked around at the onlookers - "the other thing?"

"ðeɪ tʊk ðət bæk, tu," ɹænd sɛd kwaɪətli. ɪŋtʃɹ paʊndɪɾ ə fɪst ɪndə hɪz pɑm ən tɝn əweɪ; səm ə ðə kɛɹhinɪn bækt ɔf fɹəm ðə lʊk ɑn ɪz feɪs.

"They took that back, too," Rand said quietly. Ingtar pounded a fist into his palm and turned away; some of the Cairhienin backed off from the look on his face.

mæt tʃuɾ ɪz lɪp, ðən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "aɪ dɪdnt noʊ ɪt wɑz faʊnd, soʊ ɪɾ ɪzən əz ɪf aɪ hæd lɔst ɪɾ əɡɛn. ɪts dʒʌst stɪl lɔst." ɪt wɑz pleɪn i wɑz spikɪŋ ə ðə dæɡɝ, nɑt ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ. "wil faɪn ɪɾ əɡɛn. wɪv tu snɪfɝz, naʊ. pɛɹɪn ɪz wʌn, tu. hi fɑloʊd ðə tʃɹeɪl ɔl ðə weɪ tə ðə fɔɹɡeɪt, æftɝ jə vænɪʃt wɪð hʊɹɪn ən lɔɪəl. aɪ θɔt jə maɪɾ əv dʒʌst ɹʌn ɔf . . . wɛl, jə noʊ wʌɾ aɪ min. wɛɹ dɪd jə ɡoʊ? aɪ stɪl doʊn ʌndɝstæn haʊ jə ɡɑt soʊ fɑɹ əhɛɾ ʌv ʌs. ðət fɛloʊ sɛd juv bɪn hɪɹ deɪz."
