Mat chewed his lip, then shook his head. "I didn't know it was found, so it isn't as if I had lost it again. It is just still lost." It was plain he was speaking of the dagger, not the Horn of Valere. "We'll find it again. We have two sniffers, now. Perrin is one, too. He followed the trail all the way to the Foregate, after you vanished with Hurin and Loial. I thought you might have just run off . . . well, you know what I mean. Where did you go? I still don't understand how you got so far ahead of us. That fellow said you have been here days."

ɹænd ɡlænst ət pɛɹɪn - hiz ə snɪfɝ? - ən faʊn pɛɹɪn stʌɾiɪŋ ɪm ɪn ɹɪtɝn. hi θɔt pɛɹɪn mʌɾɝd sʌmθɪŋ. ʃæɾoʊkɪlɝ? aɪ mʌst əv hɝɾ ɪm ɹɔŋ. pɛɹɪnz jɛloʊ ɡeɪz hɛld ɪm fəɹ ə moʊmənt, simɪŋ tə hoʊl sikɹəts əbaʊt hɪm. tɛlɪŋ hɪmsɛlf i wɑz hævɪŋ fænsiz - aɪm nɑt mæd. nɑt jɛt. - hi pʊld ɪz aɪz əweɪ.

Rand glanced at Perrin - He's a sniffer? - and found Perrin studying him in return. He thought Perrin muttered something. Shadowkiller? I must have heard him wrong. Perrin's yellow gaze held him for a moment, seeming to hold secrets about him. Telling himself he was having fancies - I'm not mad. Not yet. - he pulled his eyes away.

vɛɹɪn wɑz dʒʌs hɛlpɪŋ ə stɪl-ʃeɪki hʊɹɪn tə hɪz fit. "aɪ fil ɹaɪɾ əz ɡus fɛðɝz," hi wɑz seɪɪŋ. "stɪl ə lɪɾəl taɪɝd, bʌt. . . ." hi lɛt ðə wɝdz tʃɹeɪl ɔf, simɪŋ tə si hɝ fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm, tə ɹilaɪz wʌt hæd hæpən fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm.

Verin was just helping a still-shaky Hurin to his feet. "I feel right as goose feathers," he was saying. "Still a little tired, but. . . ." He let the words trail off, seeming to see her for the first time, to realize what had happened for the first time.

"ðə taɪɹədnəs wɪl læst ə fju aʊɝz," ʃi toʊl hɪm. "ðə bɑɾi mʌst stʃɹeɪn tə hil ɪtsɛlf kwɪkli."

"The tiredness will last a few hours," she told him. "The body must strain to heal itself quickly."

ðə kɛɹhinɪn ɹiɾɝ ɹoʊz. "ɛɛs sədaɪ?" ʃi sɛd sɔfli. vɛɹɪn ɪnklaɪn əɹ hɛd, ən ðə ɹiɾɝ meɪɾ ə fʊl kɝtsi.

The Cairhienin Reader rose. "Aes Sedai?" she said softly. Verin inclined her head, and the Reader made a full curtsy.

əz kwaɪəɾ əz ðeɪ hæd bɪn, ðə wɝdz "ɛɛs sədaɪ" ɹæn θɹu ðə kɹaʊɾ ɪn toʊnz ɹeɪnʒɪŋ fɹəm ɑ tə fɪɹ tə aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ. ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ naʊ - nɑɾ ivən kueɪli ɡeɪv ɛni ətɛnʃən tə hɪz oʊn bɝnɪŋ ɪn - ən ɹænd θɔɾ ə lɪɾəl kɑʃən maɪt nɑt bi əmɪs æftɝ ɔl.

As quiet as they had been, the words "Aes Sedai" ran through the crowd in tones ranging from awe to fear to outrage. Everyone was watching now - not even Cuale gave any attention to his own burning inn - and Rand thought a little caution might not be amiss after all.

"du juv ɹumz jɛt?" hi æskt. "wi nid tə tɔk, ən wi kæn də ɪt hɪɹ."

"Do you have rooms yet?" he asked. "We need to talk, and we can't do it here."

"ə ɡʊɾ aɪdiə," vɛɹɪn sɛd. "aɪ hæv steɪd hɪɹ bɪfɔɹ ət ðə ɡɹeɪt tʃɹi. wɪl ɡoʊ ðɛɹ."

"A good idea," Verin said. "I have stayed here before at The Great Tree. We will go there."

lɔɪəl wɛn tə fɛtʃ ðə hɔɹsəz - ði ɪn ɹuf hæd naʊ fɔlən ɪn kəmplitli, bʌt ðə steɪbəlz hæd nɑt bɪn tʌtʃt - ən sun ðeɪ wɝ meɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ weɪ θɹu ðə stʃɹits, ɔl ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪksɛp fəɹ lɔɪəl, hu kleɪmd i hæd ɡɹoʊn juz tə wɔkɪŋ əɡɛn. pɛɹɪn hɛl ðə lɛd laɪn tə wʌn ə ðə pækhɔɹsɪz ðeɪ hæd bɹɔt saʊθ.

Loial went to fetch the horses - the inn roof had now fallen in completely, but the stables had not been touched - and soon they were making their way through the streets, all riding except for Loial, who claimed he had grown used to walking again. Perrin held the lead line to one of the packhorses they had brought south.

"hʊɹɪn," ɹænd sɛd, "haʊ sun kən jə bi ɹɛɾi tə fɑloʊ ðɛɹ tʃɹeɪl əɡɛn? kən jə fɑloʊ ɪt? ðə mɛn u hɪt jə ən stɑɹɾəd ðə faɪɝ lɛft ə tʃɹeɪl, dɪdn ðeɪ?"

"Hurin," Rand said, "how soon can you be ready to follow their trail again? Can you follow it? The men who hit you and started the fire left a trail, didn't they?"

"aɪ kən fɑloʊ ɪt naʊ, maɪ lɔɹd. ən aɪ kəd smɛl əm ɪn ðə stʃɹit. ɪt woʊn læs lɔŋ, ðoʊ. ðəɹ wɝn ɛni tʃɹɑləks, ən ðeɪ dɪdn kɪl ɛnibəɾi. dʒʌs mɛn, maɪ lɔɹd. dɑɹkfɹɛnz, aɪ səpoʊz, bʌt jə kæn ɔlweɪz bi ʃʊɹ ə ðət baɪ smɛl. ə deɪ, meɪbi, bɪfɔɹ ɪt feɪdz."

"I can follow it now, my Lord. And I could smell them in the street. It won't last long, though. There weren't any Trollocs, and they didn't kill anybody. Just men, my Lord. Darkfriends, I suppose, but you can't always be sure of that by smell. A day, maybe, before it fades."

"aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðeɪ kən oʊpən ðə tʃɛst iðɝ, ɹænd," lɔɪəl sɛd, "ɔɹ ðeɪ wəd dʒʌst əv teɪkən ðə hɔɹn. ɪt wəd bi mʌtʃ iziɝ tə teɪk ðəɾ ɪf ðeɪ kʊd, ɹæðɝ ðən ðə hoʊl tʃɛst."

"I don't think they can open the chest either, Rand," Loial said, "or they would just have taken the Horn. It would be much easier to take that if they could, rather than the whole chest."

ɹænd nɑɾəd. "ðeɪ mʌst əv pʊɾ ɪɾ ɪn ə kɑɹt, əɹ ɑn ə hɔɹs. wʌns ðeɪ ɡɛɾ ɪt bɪɑn ðə fɔɹɡeɪt, ðəl dʒɔɪn ðə tʃɹɑləks əɡɛn, fəɹ ʃʊɹ. jəl bi eɪbəl tə fɑloʊ ðət tʃɹeɪl, hʊɹɪn."

Rand nodded. "They must have put it in a cart, or on a horse. Once they get it beyond the Foregate, they'll join the Trollocs again, for sure. You will be able to follow that trail, Hurin."

"aɪ wɪl, maɪ lɔɹd."

"I will, my Lord."

"ðɛn jə ɹɛst əntɪl jəɹ fɪt," ɹænd toʊl hɪm. ðə snɪfɝ lʊk stɛɾiɝ, bʌɾ i ɹoʊd slʌmpt, ən ɪz feɪs wɑz wɪɹi. "æt bɛst, ðəl oʊnli bi ə fju aʊɝz əhɛɾ ʌv ʌs. ɪf wi ɹaɪd hɑɹd. . . ." sʌɾənli hi noʊɾəst ðət ði ʌðɝz wɝ lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm, vɛɹɪn ən ɪŋtʃɹ, mæt ən pɛɹɪn. hi ɹilaɪzd wʌɾ i hæd bɪn duɪŋ, ən ɪz feɪs kʌlɝd. "aɪ æm sɑɹi, ɪŋtʃɹ. ɪts dʒʌs ðəɾ aɪv bɪkʌm juz tə biɪŋ ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ, aɪ səpoʊz. aɪm nɑt tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə teɪk jəɹ pleɪs."

"Then you rest until you're fit," Rand told him. The sniffer looked steadier, but he rode slumped, and his face was weary. "At best, they will only be a few hours ahead of us. If we ride hard. . . ." Suddenly he noticed that the others were looking at him, Verin and Ingtar, Mat and Perrin. He realized what he had been doing, and his face colored. "I am sorry, Ingtar. It's just that I've become used to being in charge, I suppose. I'm not trying to take your place."

ɪŋtʃɹ nɑɾəd sloʊli. "mɔɪɹeɪn tʃoʊz wɛl wən ʃi meɪd lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ neɪm jə maɪ sɛkənd. pɝhæps ɪt wʊɾə bɪn bɛɾɝ ɪf ði æmɪɝlɪn sit hæd ɡɪvən jə ðə tʃɑɹdʒ." ðə ʃaɪnɝən bɑɹkt ə læf. "æt lis juv æktʃəli  mænədʒ tə tʌtʃ ðə hɔɹn."

Ingtar nodded slowly. "Moiraine chose well when she made Lord Agelmar name you my second. Perhaps it would have been better if the Amyrlin Seat had given you the charge." The Shienaran barked a laugh. "At least you have actually managed to touch the Horn."

æftɝ ðət ðeɪ ɹoʊɾ ɪn saɪləns.

After that they rode in silence.

ðə ɡɹeɪt tʃɹi cʊɾə bɪn twɪn tə ðə dɪfɛndɝ ə ðə dʒɹæɡoʊnwɔl, ə tɔl stoʊn kjub ʌv ə bɪldɪŋ wɪð ə kɑmən ɹum pænəld ɪn dɑɹk wʊɾ ən dɛkɝeɪɾəd wɪð sɪlvɝ, ə lɑɹdʒ, pɑlɪʃt klɑk ɑn ðə mæntəl oʊvɝ ðə faɪɝpleɪs. ði ɪnkipɝ cʊɾə bɪn kueɪliz sɪstɝ. mɪstʃɹəs tidʒɹə hæd ðə seɪm slaɪtli plʌmp lʊk ən ðə seɪm ʌŋtʃwəs mænɝ - ən ðə seɪm ʃɑɹp aɪz, ðə seɪm ɛɹ ə lɪsnɪŋ tə wʌt wɑz bɪhaɪn ðə wɝdz jə spoʊk. bʌt tidʒɹə nu vɛɹɪn, ən əɹ wɛlkəmɪŋ smaɪl fəɹ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑz wɔɹm; ʃi nɛvɝ mɛnʃən ɛɛs sədaɪ əlaʊd, bʌt ɹænd wɑz ʃʊɹ ʃi nu.

The Great Tree could have been twin to The Defender of the Dragonwall, a tall stone cube of a building with a common room paneled in dark wood and decorated with silver, a large, polished clock on the mantel over the fireplace. The innkeeper could have been Cuale's sister. Mistress Tiedra had the same slightly plump look and the same unctuous manner - and the same sharp eyes, the same air of listening to what was behind the words you spoke. But Tiedra knew Verin, and her welcoming smile for the Aes Sedai was warm; she never mentioned Aes Sedai aloud, but Rand was sure she knew.

tidʒɹə ən ə swɔɹm ə sɝvəns sɔ tə ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz ən sɛɾəld əm ɪn ðɛɹ ɹumz. ɹændz ɹum wɑz əz faɪn əz ðə wʌn ðət hæd bɝnd, bʌɾ i wɑz mɔɹ ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn ðə bɪɡ kɑpɝ bæθtəb tu sɝvɪŋ mɛn ɹɛsəl θɹu ðə dɔɹ, ən ðə stimɪŋ bʌkəts ʌv wɔɾɝ skʌlɝi meɪdz bɹɔɾ ʌp fɹəm ðə kɪtʃən. wʌn lʊk ɪn ðə mɪɹɝ əbʌv ðə wɑʃstænd ʃoʊɾ ɪm ə feɪs ðət lʊkt əz ɪf i hæd ɹʌbd ɪt wɪð tʃɑɹkoʊl, ən ɪz koʊt hæd blæk smɪɹz əkɹɔs ðə ɹɛd wʊl.

Tiedra and a swarm of servants saw to their horses and settled them in their rooms. Rand's room was as fine as the one that had burned, but he was more interested in the big copper bathtub two serving men wrestled through the door, and the steaming buckets of water scullery maids brought up from the kitchen. One look in the mirror above the washstand showed him a face that looked as if he had rubbed it with charcoal, and his coat had black smears across the red wool.

hi stʃɹɪpt ɔf ən klaɪmd ɪndə ðə tʌb, bʌɾ i θɔɾ əz mʌtʃ əz wɑʃt. vɛɹɪn wɑz ðɛɹ. wʌn ə θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ ðəɾ i kəd tʃɹʌs nɑt tə tʃɹaɪ tə dʒɛntəl ɪm ðɛmsɛlvz, əɹ tɝn ɪm oʊvɝ tə ðoʊz u wʊd. əɹ soʊ ɪt simd, ət list. wʌn ə θɹi hu wɑntəɾ ɪm tə bɪliv i wɑz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, tə juz ɪm əz ə fɔls dʒɹæɡən. ʃiz mɔɪɹeɪnz aɪz wɑtʃɪŋ mi, mɔɪɹeɪnz hæn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʊl maɪ stʃɹɪŋz. bʌɾ aɪ hæv kʌt ðə stʃɹɪŋz.

He stripped off and climbed into the tub, but he thought as much as washed. Verin was there. One of three Aes Sedai that he could trust not to try to gentle him themselves, or turn him over to those who would. Or so it seemed, at least. One of three who wanted him to believe he was the Dragon Reborn, to use him as a false Dragon. She's Moiraine's eyes watching me, Moiraine's hand trying to pull my strings. But I have cut the strings.

hɪz sæɾəlbæɡz hæd bɪn bɹɔɾ ʌp, ən ə bʌndəl fɹəm ðə pæk hɔɹs kənteɪnɪŋ fɹɛʃ kloʊðz. hi taʊəld ɔf ən oʊpən ðə bʌndəl - ən saɪd. hi hæd fɝɡɑɾən ðət boʊθ ði ʌðɝ koʊts i hæd wɝ əz ɔɹneɪɾ əz ðə wʌn i hæd tɔst ɑn ðə bæk ʌv ə tʃɛɹ fəɹ ə meɪd tə klin. æftɝ ə moʊmənt, hi tʃoʊz ðə blæk koʊt, tə suɾ ɪz mud. sɪlvɝ hɛɹənz stʊɾ ɑn ðə haɪ kɑlɝ, ən sɪlvɝ ɹæpədz ɹæn daʊn ɪz slivz, wɔɾɝ bæɾɝd tə fɹɔθ əɡɛns dʒæɡd ɹɑks.

His saddlebags had been brought up, and a bundle from the pack horse containing fresh clothes. He toweled off and opened the bundle - and sighed. He had forgotten that both the other coats he had were as ornate as the one he had tossed on the back of a chair for a maid to clean. After a moment, he chose the black coat, to suit his mood. Silver herons stood on the high collar, and silver rapids ran down his sleeves, water battered to froth against jagged rocks.

tʃɹænsfɝɪŋ θɪŋz fɹəm ɪz oʊl koʊt tə hɪz nu, hi faʊn ðə pɑɹtʃməns. æbsənli, hi stʌf ði ɪnvɪteɪʃənz ɪn ɪz pɑkəɾ əz i stʌɾid səlinz tu lɛɾɝz. hi wʌndɝd haʊ hi cʊɾə bɪn sətʃ ə ful. ʃi wɑz ðə bjuɾəfəl jʌŋ dɔɾɝ ʌv ə noʊbəl haʊs. hi wɑz ə ʃɛpɝd hum ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə juz, ə mæn dum tə ɡoʊ mæɾ ɪf i dɪd nɑt daɪ fɝst. jɛɾ i kəd stɪl fil ðə pʊl ə hɝ dʒʌs lʊkɪŋ əɾ əɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ, kəɾ ɔlmoʊst smɛl ðə pɝfjum ə hɝ.

Transferring things from his old coat to his new, he found the parchments. Absently, he stuffed the invitations in his pocket as he studied Selene's two letters. He wondered how he could have been such a fool. She was the beautiful young daughter of a noble House. He was a shepherd whom Aes Sedai were trying to use, a man doomed to go mad if he did not die first. Yet he could still feel the pull of her just looking at her writing, could almost smell the perfume of her.

"aɪ æm ə ʃɛpɝd," hi toʊl ðə lɛɾɝz, "nɑɾ ə ɡɹeɪt mæn, ən ɪf aɪ kəd mɛɹi ɛniwʌn, ɪt wəd bi ɛɡwin, bʌt ʃi wɑns tə bi ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən haʊ kən aɪ mɛɹi ɛni wʊmən, lʌv ɛni wʊmən, wən əl ɡoʊ mæɾ ən meɪbi kɪl hɝ?"

"I am a shepherd," he told the letters, "not a great man, and if I could marry anyone, it would be Egwene, but she wants to be Aes Sedai, and how can I marry any woman, love any woman, when I'll go mad and maybe kill her?"

wɝdz kəd nɑt lɛsən ɪz mɛmɹi ʌv səlinz bjuɾi, ðoʊ, əɹ ðə weɪ ʃi meɪɾ ɪz blʌd ɡoʊ wɔɹm dʒʌs baɪ lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm. ɪɾ ɔlmoʊst sim tə hɪm ðət ʃi wɑz ɪn ðə ɹum wɪð hɪm, ðəɾ i kəd smɛl əɹ pɝfjum, soʊ mʌtʃ soʊ ðəɾ i lʊkt ɝaʊnd, ən læf tə faɪn hɪmsɛlf əloʊn.

Words could not lessen his memory of Selene's beauty, though, or the way she made his blood go warm just by looking at him. It almost seemed to him that she was in the room with him, that he could smell her perfume, so much so that he looked around, and laughed to find himself alone.

"hævɪŋ fænsiz laɪk aɪm æɾəld ɔlɹɛɾi," hi mʌɾɝd.

"Having fancies like I'm addled already," he muttered.

əbɹʌpli hi tɪp bæk ðə mæntəl ə ðə læmp ɑn ðə bɛdsaɪd teɪbəl, lɪɾ ɪt, ən θɹʌs ðə lɛɾɝz ɪndə ðə fleɪm. aʊtsaɪd ði ɪn, ðə wɪn pɪkt ʌp tə ə ɹɔɹ, likɪŋ ɪn θɹu ðə ʃʌɾɝz ən fænɪŋ ðə fleɪmz tə ɪnɡʌlf ðə pɑɹtʃmənt. hɝidli hi tɔs ðə bɝnɪŋ lɛɾɝz ɪndə ðə koʊl hɑɹθ dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ ðə faɪɝ ɹitʃt ɪz fɪŋɡɝz. hi weɪɾəd əntɪl ðə læs blækən kɝl wɛn aʊt bɪfɔɹ i bʌkəld ɑn ɪz sɔɹɾ ən lɛf ðə ɹum.

Abruptly he tipped back the mantle of the lamp on the bedside table, lit it, and thrust the letters into the flame. Outside the inn, the wind picked up to a roar, leaking in through the shutters and fanning the flames to engulf the parchment. Hurriedly he tossed the burning letters into the cold hearth just before the fire reached his fingers. He waited until the last blackened curl went out before he buckled on his sword and left the room.

vɛɹɪn hæd teɪkən ə pɹaɪvət daɪnɪŋ ɹum, wɛɹ ʃɛlvz əlɔŋ ðə dɑɹk wɔlz hɛld ivən mɔɹ sɪlvɝ ðən ðoʊz ɪn ðə kɑmən ɹum. mæt wɑz dʒʌɡəlɪŋ θɹi bɔɪld ɛɡz ən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə əpɪɹ nɑnʃəlɑnt. ɪŋtʃɹ pɪɹɾ ɪndə ði ənlɪt faɪɝpleɪs, fɹaʊnɪŋ. lɔɪəl hæɾ ə fju bʊks fɹəm fæl dæɹə stɪl ɪn ɪz pɑkəts, ən wɑz ɹiɾɪŋ wʌn bɪsaɪɾ ə læmp.

Verin had taken a private dining room, where shelves along the dark walls held even more silver than those in the common room. Mat was juggling three boiled eggs and trying to appear nonchalant. Ingtar peered into the unlit fireplace, frowning. Loial had a few books from Fal Dara still in his pockets, and was reading one beside a lamp.

pɛɹɪn slaʊtʃt ət ðə teɪbəl, stʌɾiɪŋ ɪz hænz klæspt ɑn ðə teɪbəltɑp. tə hɪz noʊz, ðə ɹum smɛld ə biswæks juz tə pɑlɪʃ ðə pænəlɪŋ. ɪt wɑz hɪm, hi θɔt. ɹænd ɪz ðə ʃæɾoʊkɪlɝ. laɪt, wʌts hæpənɪŋ tə ɔl ʌv ʌs? hɪz hænz taɪɾənd ɪndə fɪsts, lɑɹdʒ ən skwɛɹ. ðiz hænz wɝ mɛn fəɹ ə smɪθs hæmɝ, nɑɾ ən æks.

Perrin slouched at the table, studying his hands clasped on the tabletop. To his nose, the room smelled of beeswax used to polish the paneling. It was him, he thought. Rand is the Shadowkiller. Light, what's happening to all of us? His hands tightened into fists, large and square. These hands were meant for a smith's hammer, not an axe.

hi ɡlænst ʌp əz ɹænd ɛntɝd. pɛɹɪn θɔɾ i lʊk dɪtɝmənd, sɛɾ ɑn səm kɔɹs ʌv ækʃən. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ moʊʃən ɹænd tə ə haɪ-bækt ɑɹmtʃɛɹ əkɹɔs fɹəm hɝ.

He glanced up as Rand entered. Perrin thought he looked determined, set on some course of action. The Aes Sedai motioned Rand to a high-backed armchair across from her.

"haʊ ɪz hʊɹɪn?" ɹænd æsk hɝ, ɝeɪnʒɪŋ ɪz sɔɹd soʊ hi kəd sɪt. "ɹɛstɪŋ?"

"How is Hurin?" Rand asked her, arranging his sword so he could sit. "Resting?"

"hi ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn ɡoʊɪŋ aʊt," ɪŋtʃɹ ænsɝd. "aɪ toʊld ɪm tə fɑloʊ ðə tʃɹeɪl oʊnli əntɪl i smɛl tʃɹɑləks. wi kən fɑloʊ ɪt fɹəm ðəɹ təmɑɹoʊ. əɹ dʒju wɑnə ɡoʊ æftɝ əm tənaɪt?"

"He insisted on going out," Ingtar answered. "I told him to follow the trail only until he smelled Trollocs. We can follow it from there tomorrow. Or do you want to go after them tonight?"

"ɪŋtʃɹ," ɹænd sɛɾ ənizəli, "aɪ ɹɪli wɑzn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə teɪk kəmænd. aɪ dʒʌs dɪdn θɪŋk." jɛt nɑɾ əz nɝvəsli əz i wəɾ əv wʌns, pɛɹɪn θɔt. ʃæɾoʊkɪlɝ. wɝ ɔl ʌv əs tʃeɪnʒɪŋ.

"Ingtar," Rand said uneasily, "I really wasn't trying to take command. I just didn't think." Yet not as nervously as he would have once, Perrin thought. Shadowkiller. We're all of us changing.

ɪŋtʃɹ dɪd nɑɾ ænsɝ, bʌɾ oʊnli kɛp stɛɹɪŋ ɪndə ðə faɪɝpleɪs.

Ingtar did not answer, but only kept staring into the fireplace.

"ðɛɹ ɑɹ səm θɪŋz ðəɾ ɪntʃɹəs mi ɡɹeɪtli, ɹænd," vɛɹɪn sɛd kwaɪətli. "wʌn ɪz haʊ jə vænɪʃt fɹəm ɪŋtʃɹz kæmp wɪθaʊɾ ə tʃɹeɪs. ənʌðɝ ɪz haʊ jə ɝaɪvd ɪn kɛɹhin ə wik bɪfɔɹ ʌs. ðət klɝk wɑz vɛɹi klɪɹ ɑn ðæt. jə wʊɾə hæd tə flaɪ."

"There are some things that interest me greatly, Rand," Verin said quietly. "One is how you vanished from Ingtar's camp without a trace. Another is how you arrived in Cairhien a week before us. That clerk was very clear on that. You would have had to fly."

wʌn ə mæts ɛɡz hɪt ðə flɔɹ ən kɹækt. hi dɪd nɑt lʊk əɾ ɪt, ðoʊ. hi wɑz lʊkɪŋ ət ɹænd, ən ɪŋtʃɹ hæd tɝn ɝaʊnd. lɔɪəl pɹitɛndəd tə bi ɹiɾɪŋ stɪl, bʌɾ i wɔɹ ə wɝid lʊk, ən ɪz ɪɹz wɝ ʌp ɪn hɛɹi pɔɪns.

One of Mat's eggs hit the floor and cracked. He did not look at it, though. He was looking at Rand, and Ingtar had turned around. Loial pretended to be reading still, but he wore a worried look, and his ears were up in hairy points.

pɛɹɪn ɹilaɪzd i wɑz stɛɹɪŋ, tu. "wɛl, hi dɪd nɑt flaɪ," hi sɛd. "aɪ doʊn si ɛni wɪŋz. meɪbi hiz mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt θɪŋz tə tɛl ʌs." vɛɹɪn ʃɪftəɾ əɹ ətɛnʃən tə hɪm, dʒʌs fəɹ ə moʊmənt. hi mænədʒ tə miɾ əɹ aɪz, bʌɾ i wɑz ðə fɝs tə lʊk əweɪ. ɛɛs sədaɪ. laɪt, waɪ wɝ wi ɛvɝ fulz ɪnʌf tə fɑloʊ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ? ɹænd ɡeɪv ɪm ə ɡɹeɪtfəl lʊk, tu, ən pɛɹɪn ɡɹɪn ət hɪm. hi wɑz nɑt ði oʊld ɹænd - hi sim tə hæv ɡɹoʊn ɪndə ðət fænsi koʊt; ɪt lʊkt ɹaɪɾ ɑn hɪm, naʊ - bʌɾ i wɑz stɪl ðə bɔɪ pɛɹɪn hæd ɡɹoʊn ʌp wɪð. ʃæɾoʊkɪlɝ. ə mæn ðə wʊlvz hoʊld ɪn ɑ. ə mæn u kən tʃænəl.

Perrin realized he was staring, too. "Well, he did not fly," he said. "I don't see any wings. Maybe he has more important things to tell us." Verin shifted her attention to him, just for a moment. He managed to meet her eyes, but he was the first to look away. Aes Sedai. Light, why were we ever fools enough to follow an Aes Sedai? Rand gave him a grateful look, too, and Perrin grinned at him. He was not the old Rand - he seemed to have grown into that fancy coat; it looked right on him, now - but he was still the boy Perrin had grown up with. Shadowkiller. A man the wolves hold in awe. A man who can channel.

"aɪ doʊn maɪnd," ɹænd sɛd, ən toʊld ɪz teɪl sɪmpli.

"I don't mind," Rand said, and told his tale simply.

pɛɹɪn faʊn hɪmsɛlf ɡeɪpɪŋ. pɔɹɾəl stoʊnz. ʌðɝ wɝlz, wɛɹ ðə læn sim tə ʃɪft. hʊɹɪn fɑloʊɪŋ ðə tʃɹeɪl ʌv wɛɹ ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz wəd bi. ən ə bjuɾəfəl wʊmən ɪn dɪstʃɹɛs, dʒʌs laɪk wʌn ɪn ə ɡlimənz teɪl.

Perrin found himself gaping. Portal Stones. Other worlds, where the land seemed to shift. Hurin following the trail of where the Darkfriends would be. And a beautiful woman in distress, just like one in a gleeman's tale.

mæt ɡeɪv ə sɑft, wʌndɝɪŋ wɪsəl. "ænd ʃi bɹɔt jə bæk? baɪ wʌn ə ðiz - ðiz stoʊnz?"

Mat gave a soft, wondering whistle. "And she brought you back? By one of these - these Stones?"

ɹænd hɛzɪteɪɾɪd fəɹ ə sɛkənd. "ʃi mʌs hæv," hi sɛd. "soʊ jə si, ðæts haʊ wi ɡɑt soʊ fɑɹ əhɛɾ ə ju. wən feɪn keɪm, lɔɪəl ən aɪ mænədʒ tə stil bæk ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ ɪn ðə naɪt, ən wi ɹoʊɾ ɑn tə kɛɹhin kəz aɪ dɪdn θɪŋk wi kəd meɪk ɪt pæst əm wʌns ðeɪ wɝ ɹaʊzd, ən aɪ nu ɪŋtʃɹ wəd kip kʌmɪŋ saʊθ æftɝ əm ən ɹitʃ kɛɹhin ɪvɛntʃəwəli."

Rand hesitated for a second. "She must have," he said. "So you see, that's how we got so far ahead of you. When Fain came, Loial and I managed to steal back the Horn of Valere in the night, and we rode on to Cairhien because I didn't think we could make it past them once they were roused, and I knew Ingtar would keep coming south after them and reach Cairhien eventually."

ʃæɾoʊkɪlɝ. ɹænd lʊkt ət hɪm, aɪz nɛɹoʊɪŋ, ən pɛɹɪn ɹilaɪzd i hæd spoʊkən ðə neɪm əlaʊd. əpɛɹənli nɑt laʊɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ ɛniwʌn ɛls tə hɪɹ, ðoʊ. noʊ wʌn ɛls ɡlænst ət hɪm. hi faʊn hɪmsɛlf wɑntɪŋ tə tɛl ɹænd əbaʊt ðə wʊlvz. aɪ noʊ əbaʊt ju. ɪts oʊnli fɛɹ jə noʊ maɪ sikɹət, tu. bʌt vɛɹɪn wɑz ðɛɹ. hi kəd nɑt seɪ ɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ.

Shadowkiller. Rand looked at him, eyes narrowing, and Perrin realized he had spoken the name aloud. Apparently not loud enough for anyone else to hear, though. No one else glanced at him. He found himself wanting to tell Rand about the wolves. I know about you. It's only fair you know my secret, too. But Verin was there. He could not say it in front of her.

"ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ," ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛd, ə θɔtfəl ɪkspɹɛʃən ɑn əɹ feɪs. "aɪ wəd vɛɹi mʌtʃ laɪk tə mit ðɪs ɡɝl. ɪf ʃi kən juz ə pɔɹɾəl stoʊn. . . . ivən ðət neɪm ɪz nɑt vɛɹi waɪdli noʊn." ʃi ɡeɪv hɝsɛlf ə ʃeɪk. "wɛl, ðəɾ ɪz fəɹ ənʌðɝ taɪm. ə tɔl ɡɝl ʃəd nɑt bi dɪfəkəl tə faɪn ɪn ðə kɛɹhinɪn haʊsəz. ɑ, hɪɹ ɪz əɹ mil."

"Interesting," the Aes Sedai said, a thoughtful expression on her face. "I would very much like to meet this girl. If she can use a Portal Stone. . . . Even that name is not very widely known." She gave herself a shake. "Well, that is for another time. A tall girl should not be difficult to find in the Cairhienin Houses. Aah, here is our meal."

pɛɹɪn smɛld læm ivən bɪfɔɹ mɪstʃɹəs tidʒɹə lɛɾ ɪn ə pɹəsɛʃən bɛɹɪŋ tʃɹeɪz ə fud. hɪz maʊθ wɔɾɝd mɔɹ fəɹ ðət ðən fəɹ ðə piz ən skwɑʃ, ðə kæɹəts ən kæbədʒ ðət keɪm wɪð ɪt, əɹ ðə hɑt kɹʌsti ɹoʊlz. hi stɪl faʊn vɛdʒtəbəlz teɪsti, bʌt səmtaɪmz, ʌv leɪt, hi dʒɹimd ə ɹɛd mit. nɑɾ ivən kʊkt, juʒəwəli. ɪt wɑz dɪskənsɝɾɪŋ tə faɪn hɪmsɛlf θɪŋkɪŋ ðət ðə naɪsli pɪŋk slaɪsəz ə læm ðət ði ɪnkipɝ kɑɹvd wɝ tu wɛl dʌn. hi fɝmli tʊk hɛlpɪŋz ʌv ɛvɹiθɪŋ. ən tu ʌv ðə læm.

Perrin smelled lamb even before Mistress Tiedra led in a procession bearing trays of food. His mouth watered more for that than for the peas and squash, the carrots and cabbage that came with it, or the hot crusty rolls. He still found vegetables tasty, but sometimes, of late, he dreamed of red meat. Not even cooked, usually. It was disconcerting to find himself thinking that the nicely pink slices of lamb that the innkeeper carved were too well done. He firmly took helpings of everything. And two of the lamb.

ɪt wɑz ə kwaɪət mil, wɪð ɛvɹiwʌn kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾɪŋ ɑn ɪz oʊn θɔts. pɛɹɪn faʊn ɪt peɪnfəl tə wɑtʃ mæt it. mæts æpətaɪt wɑz əz hɛlθi əz ɛvɝ, dɪspaɪt ðə fivɝɪʃ flʌʃ tə hɪz feɪs, ən ðə weɪ hi ʃʌvəl fuɾ ɪndə hɪz maʊθ meɪɾ ɪt lʊk laɪk ɪz læs mil bɪfɔɹ daɪɪŋ. pɛɹɪn kɛpt ɪz aɪz ɑn ɪz pleɪɾ əz mʌtʃ əz pɑsəbəl, ən wɪʃt ðeɪ hæd nɛvɝ lɛft ɛmənz fild.

It was a quiet meal, with everyone concentrating on his own thoughts. Perrin found it painful to watch Mat eat. Mat's appetite was as healthy as ever, despite the feverish flush to his face, and the way he shoveled food into his mouth made it look like his last meal before dying. Perrin kept his eyes on his plate as much as possible, and wished they had never left Emond's Field.

æftɝ ðə meɪdz klɪɹd ðə teɪbəl ən lɛft əɡɛn, vɛɹɪn ɪnsɪstəd ðeɪ ɹɪmeɪn təɡɛðɝ əntɪl hʊɹɪn ɹɪtɝnd. "hi meɪ bɹɪŋ wɝd ðət wɪl min wi mʌs muv ət wʌns."

After the maids cleared the table and left again, Verin insisted they remain together until Hurin returned. "He may bring word that will mean we must move at once."

mæt ɹɪtɝn tə hɪz dʒʌɡəlɪŋ, ən lɔɪəl tə hɪz ɹiɾɪŋ. ɹænd æsk ði ɪnkipɝ ɪf ðəɹ wɝ ɛni mɔɹ bʊks, ən ʃi bɹɔɾ ɪm ðə tʃɹævəlz ə dʒaɪn fɑɹstʃɹaɪɾɝ. pɛɹɪn laɪk ðət wʌn, tu, wɪð ɪts stɔɹiz ʌv ædvɛntʃɝz əmʌŋ ðə si foʊk ən dʒɝniz tə ðə lænz bɪɑn ði il weɪst, wɛɹ sɪlk keɪm fɹʌm. hi dɪd nɑt fil laɪk ɹiɾɪŋ, ðoʊ, soʊ hi sɛɾ ʌp ə stoʊnz bɔɹɾ ɑn ðə teɪbəl wɪð ɪŋtʃɹ. ðə ʃaɪnɝən pleɪd wɪð ə slæʃɪŋ, dɛɹɪŋ staɪl. pɛɹɪn hæɾ ɔlweɪz pleɪd dɔɡədli, ɡɪvɪŋ ɡɹaʊn ɹɪlʌktənli, bʌɾ i faʊn hɪmsɛlf pleɪsɪŋ ðə stoʊnz wɪð əz mʌtʃ ɹɛkləsnəs əz ɪŋtʃɹ. moʊst ə ðə ɡeɪmz ɛndəɾ ɪn ə dʒɹɔ, bʌɾ i mænədʒ tə wɪn əz mɛni əz ɪŋtʃɹ dɪd. ðə ʃaɪnɝən wɑz aɪɪŋ ɪm wɪð ə nu ɹɪspɛk baɪ ɝli ivnɪŋ, wən ðə snɪfɝ ɹɪtɝnd.

Mat returned to his juggling, and Loial to his reading. Rand asked the innkeeper if there were any more books, and she brought him The Travels of Jain Farstrider. Perrin liked that one, too, with its stories of adventures among the Sea Folk and journeys to the lands beyond the Aiel Waste, where silk came from. He did not feel like reading, though, so he set up a stones board on the table with Ingtar. The Shienaran played with a slashing, daring style. Perrin had always played doggedly, giving ground reluctantly, but he found himself placing the stones with as much recklessness as Ingtar. Most of the games ended in a draw, but he managed to win as many as Ingtar did. The Shienaran was eyeing him with a new respect by early evening, when the sniffer returned.

hʊɹɪnz ɡɹɪn wɑz ət ðə seɪm taɪm tʃɹaɪʌmfən ən pɝplɛkst. "aɪ faʊn ðɛm, lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹ. lɔɹd ɹænd. aɪ tʃɹækt əm tə ðɛɹ lɛɹ."

Hurin's grin was at the same time triumphant and perplexed. "I found them, Lord Ingtar. Lord Rand. I tracked them to their lair."

"lɛɹ?" ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd ʃɑɹpli. "ju min ðəɹ haɪɾɪŋ sʌmwɛɹ kloʊs baɪ?"

"Lair?" Ingtar said sharply. "You mean they're hiding somewhere close by?"

"aɪ, lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹ. ðə wʌnz u tʊk ðə hɔɹn, aɪ fɑloʊd stʃɹeɪt ðɛɹ, ən ðəɹ wɑz tʃɹɑlɑk sɛn ɔl ɝaʊn ðə pleɪs, ðoʊ snikɪŋ əz ɪf ðeɪ dɪdn dɛɹ bi sin, ivən ðɛɹ. ən noʊ wʌndɝ." ðə snɪfɝ tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. "ɪts ðə ɡɹeɪt mænɝ lɔɹd bɑɹθeɪnz dʒʌs fɪnɪʃt bɪldɪŋ."

"Aye, Lord Ingtar. The ones who took the Horn, I followed straight there, and there was Trolloc scent all around the place, though sneaking as if they didn't dare be seen, even there. And no wonder." The sniffer took a deep breath. "It's the great manor Lord Barthanes just finished building."

"lɔɹd bɑɹθeɪnz!" ɪŋtʃɹ ɪkskleɪmd. "bʌɾ i . . . hiz . . . hiz. . . ."

"Lord Barthanes!" Ingtar exclaimed. "But he . . . he's . . . he's. . . ."

"ðɛɹ ɑɹ dɑɹkfɹɛnz əmʌŋ ðə haɪ əz wɛl əz ðə loʊ," vɛɹɪn sɛd smuðli. "ðə maɪɾi ɡɪv ðɛɹ soʊlz tə ðə ʃædoʊ əz ɔfən əz ðə wik." ɪŋtʃɹ skaʊld əz ɪf i dɪd nɑt wɑnə θɪŋk ə ðæt.

"There are Darkfriends among the high as well as the low," Verin said smoothly. "The mighty give their souls to the Shadow as often as the weak." Ingtar scowled as if he did not want to think of that.

"ðɛɹz ɡɑɹdz," hʊɹɪn wɛn ɑn. "wil nɑt ɡɛɾ ɪn wɪð twɛnti mɛn, nɑɾ ən ɡɛɾ aʊɾ əɡɛn. ə hʌnʒɹəd kəd də ɪt, bʌt tu wəd bi bɛɾɝ. ðæts wʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk, maɪ lɔɹd."

"There's guards," Hurin went on. "We'll not get in with twenty men, not and get out again. A hundred could do it, but two would be better. That's what I think, my Lord."

"wʌɾ əbaʊt ðə kɪŋ?" mæt dɪmændəd. "ɪf ðɪs bɑɹθeɪnz ɪz ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd, ðə kɪŋ wɪl hɛlp ʌs."

"What about the King?" Mat demanded. "If this Barthanes is a Darkfriend, the King will help us."

"aɪ æm kwaɪt ʃʊɹ," vɛɹɪn sɛd dʒɹaɪli, "ðæt ɡɔlʒɹiən ɹieɪɾən wəd muv əɡɛns bɑɹθeɪnz dəmədʒɹɾ ɑn ðə ɹumɝ ðət bɑɹθeɪnz ɪz ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd, ən ɡlæɾ ə ði ɪkskjus. aɪm ɔlsoʊ kwaɪt ʃʊɹ ɡɔlʒɹiən wəd nɛvɝ lɛt ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ aʊɾ ə hɪz ɡɹæsp wʌns i hæɾ ɪt. hi wəd bɹɪŋ ɪɾ aʊɾ ɑn fistdeɪz tə ʃoʊ ðə pipəl ən tɛl əm haʊ ɡɹeɪɾ ən maɪɾi kɛɹhin ɪz, ən noʊ wʌn wəɾ ɛvɝ si ɪɾ ɛls."

"I am quite sure," Verin said dryly, "that Galldrian Riatin would move against Barthanes Damodred on the rumor that Barthanes is a Darkfriend, and glad of the excuse. I am also quite sure Galldrian would never let the Horn of Valere out of his grasp once he had it. He would bring it out on feastdays to show the people and tell them how great and mighty Cairhien is, and no one would ever see it else."

pɛɹɪn blɪŋkt wɪð ʃɑk. "bʌt ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ əz tə bi ðəɹ wən ðə læs bæɾəl ɪz fɔt. hi kʊdn dʒʌs kip ɪt."

Perrin blinked with shock. "But the Horn of Valere has to be there when the Last Battle is fought. He couldn't just keep it."

"aɪ noʊ lɪɾəl ə kɛɹhinɪn," ɪŋtʃɹ toʊl hɪm, "bʌɾ aɪv hɝɾ ɪnʌf ʌv ɡɔlʒɹiən. hi wəd fist əs ən θæŋk əs fəɹ ðə ɡlɔɹi wi hæd bɹɔt tə kɛɹhin. hi wəd stʌf əɹ pɑkəts wɪð ɡoʊld ən hip ɑnɝz ɑn əɹ hɛdz. ən ɪf wi tʃɹaɪd tə liv wɪð ðə hɔɹn, hid kʌɾ əɹ ɑnɝd hɛdz ɔf wɪθaʊt pɔzɪŋ tə teɪk ə bɹɛθ."

"I know little of Cairhienin," Ingtar told him, "but I've heard enough of Galldrian. He would feast us and thank us for the glory we had brought to Cairhien. He would stuff our pockets with gold and heap honors on our heads. And if we tried to leave with the Horn, he'd cut our honored heads off without pausing to take a breath."

pɛɹɪn ɹæn ə hæn θɹu hɪz hɛɹ. ðə mɔɹ i faʊn aʊɾ əbaʊt kɪŋz, ðə lɛs i laɪk ðɛm.

Perrin ran a hand through his hair. The more he found out about kings, the less he liked them.

"wʌɾ əbaʊt ðə dæɡɝ?" mæt æsk dɪfəɾəntli. "hi wʊdnt wɑn ðæt, wəd hi?" ɪŋtʃɹ ɡlɛɹɾ ət hɪm, ən i ʃɪftəɾ ənkʌmftəbli. "aɪ noʊ ðə hɔɹn ɪz ɪmpɔɹɾənt, bʌɾ aɪm nɑt gɑnə bi faɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə læs bæɾəl. ðət dæɡɝ. . . ."

"What about the dagger?" Mat asked diffidently. "He wouldn't want that, would he?" Ingtar glared at him, and he shifted uncomfortably. "I know the Horn is important, but I'm not going to be fighting in the Last Battle. That dagger. . . ."

vɛɹɪn ɹɛstəɾ əɹ hænz ɑn ði ɑɹmz ə hɝ tʃɛɹ. "ɡɔlʒɹiən ʃæl nɑɾ əv ɪt, iðɝ. wʌt wi niɾ ɪz səm weɪ ɪnsaɪd bɑɹθeɪnzəz mænɝ haʊs. ɪf wi kən oʊnli faɪn ðə hɔɹn, wi meɪ ɔlsoʊ faɪn ə weɪ tə teɪk ɪt bæk. jɛs, mæt, ən ðə dæɡɝ. wʌns ɪts noʊn ðəɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪz ɪn ðə sɪɾi - wɛl, aɪ juʒəwəli əvɔɪd ðiz θɪŋz, bʌɾ ɪf aɪ lɛt slɪp tə tidʒɹə ðəɾ aɪ wəd laɪk tə si bɑɹθeɪnzəz nu mænɝ, aɪ ʃəɾ əv ən ɪnvɪteɪʃən ɪn ə deɪ əɹ tu. ɪt ʃəd nɑt bi dɪfəkəl tə bɹɪŋ ət list səm ə ðə ɹɛst ə ju. wʌɾ ɪz ɪt, hʊɹɪn?"

Verin rested her hands on the arms of her chair. "Galldrian shall not have it, either. What we need is some way inside Barthanes's manor house. If we can only find the Horn, we may also find a way to take it back. Yes, Mat, and the dagger. Once it is known that an Aes Sedai is in the city - well, I usually avoid these things, but if I let slip to Tiedra that I would like to see Barthanes's new manor, I should have an invitation in a day or two. It should not be difficult to bring at least some of the rest of you. What is it, Hurin?"

ðə snɪfɝ hæd bɪn ɹɑkɪŋ æŋkʃəsli ɑn ɪz hilz fɹəm ðə moʊmənt ʃi mɛnʃən ən ɪnvɪteɪʃən. "lɔɹd ɹænd ɔlɹɛɾi hæz wʌn. fɹəm lɔɹd bɑɹθeɪnz."

The sniffer had been rocking anxiously on his heels from the moment she mentioned an invitation. "Lord Rand already has one. From Lord Barthanes."

pɛɹɪn stɛɹɾ ət ɹænd, ən i wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn.

Perrin stared at Rand, and he was not the only one.

ɹænd pʊl tu sil pɑɹtʃməns fɹəm ɪz koʊt pɑkəɾ ən hændəɾ əm tə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪθaʊɾ ə wɝd.

Rand pulled two sealed parchments from his coat pocket and handed them to the Aes Sedai without a word.

ɪŋtʃɹ keɪm tə lʊk wʌndɝɪŋli oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ ət ðə silz. "bɑɹθeɪnz, ænd. . . . ən ɡɔlʒɹiən! ɹænd, haʊ dɪd jə kʌm baɪ ðiz? wʌɾ əv jə bɪn duɪŋ?"

Ingtar came to look wonderingly over her shoulder at the seals. "Barthanes, and. . . . And Galldrian! Rand, how did you come by these? What have you been doing?"

"nʌθɪŋ," ɹænd sɛd. "aɪ hævən dʌn ɛniθɪŋ. ðeɪ dʒʌst sɛn əm tə mi." ɪŋtʃɹ lɛɾ aʊɾ ə lɔŋ bɹɛθ. mæts maʊθ wɑz hæŋɪŋ oʊpən. "wɛl, ðeɪ dɪd dʒʌst sɛn ðɛm," ɹænd sɛd kwaɪətli. ðəɹ wɑz ə dɪɡnəɾi tə hɪm ðət pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ; ɹænd wɑz lʊkɪŋ ət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ðə ʃaɪnɝən lɔɹɾ əz ikwəlz.

"Nothing," Rand said. "I haven't done anything. They just sent them to me." Ingtar let out a long breath. Mat's mouth was hanging open. "Well, they did just send them," Rand said quietly. There was a dignity to him that Perrin did not remember; Rand was looking at the Aes Sedai and the Shienaran lord as equals.

pɛɹɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. jə ɑɹ fɪɾɪŋ ðət koʊt. wɝ ɔl tʃeɪnʒɪŋ.

Perrin shook his head. You are fitting that coat. We're all changing.

"lɔɹd ɹænd bɝn ɔl ðə ɹɛst," hʊɹɪn sɛd. "ɛvɹi deɪ ðeɪ keɪm, ən ɛvɹi deɪ hi bɝn ðɛm. əntɪl ðiz, ʌv kɔɹs. ɛvɹi deɪ fɹəm maɪtaɪɝ haʊsəz." hi saʊndəd pɹaʊd.

"Lord Rand burned all the rest," Hurin said. "Every day they came, and every day he burned them. Until these, of course. Every day from mightier Houses." He sounded proud.

"ðə wil ə taɪm wivz əs ɔl ɪndə ðə pæɾɝn əz ɪt wɪlz," vɛɹɪn sɛd, lʊkɪŋ ət ðə pɑɹtʃməns, "bʌt səmtaɪmz ɪt pɹəvaɪdz wʌt wi nid bɪfɔɹ wi noʊ wi niɾ ɪt."

"The Wheel of Time weaves us all into the Pattern as it wills," Verin said, looking at the parchments, "but sometimes it provides what we need before we know we need it."

kæʒəwəli ʃi kɹʌmpəl ðə kɪŋz ɪnvɪteɪʃən ən tɔst ɪɾ ɪndə ðə faɪɝpleɪs, wɛɹ ɪt leɪ waɪɾ ɑn ðə koʊld lɔɡz. bɹeɪkɪŋ ði ʌðɝ sil wɪð əɹ θʌm, ʃi ɹɛd. "jɛs. jɛs, ðɪs wɪl də vɛɹi wɛl."

Casually she crumpled the King's invitation and tossed it into the fireplace, where it lay white on the cold logs. Breaking the other seal with her thumb, she read. "Yes. Yes, this will do very well."

"haʊ kən aɪ ɡoʊ?" ɹænd æsk hɝ. "ðeɪ wɪl noʊ ɪm noʊ lɔɹd. aɪm ə ʃɛpɝd, ən ə fɑɹmɝ." ɪŋtʃɹ lʊk skɛptəkəl. "aɪ æm, ɪŋtʃɹ. aɪ toʊl jə aɪ æm." ɪŋtʃɹ ʃɹʌɡd; hi stɪl dɪd nɑt lʊk kənvɪnst. hʊɹɪn stɛɹɾ ət ɹænd wɪð flæt dɪsbɪlif.

"How can I go?" Rand asked her. "They will know I'm no lord. I am a shepherd, and a farmer." Ingtar looked skeptical. "I am, Ingtar. I told you I am." Ingtar shrugged; he still did not look convinced. Hurin stared at Rand with flat disbelief.

bɝn mi, pɛɹɪn θɔt, ɪf aɪ dɪdnt noʊ hɪm, aɪ wʊdn bɪliv ɪɾ iðɝ. mæt wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ ɹænd wɪð ɪz hɛd tɪltəd, fɹaʊnɪŋ əz ɪf lʊkɪŋ ət sʌmθɪŋ i hæd nɛvɝ sin bɪfɔɹ. hi siz ɪt, tu, naʊ. "ju kən də ɪt, ɹænd," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ju kæn."

Burn me, Perrin thought, if I didn't know him, I wouldn't believe it either. Mat was watching Rand with his head tilted, frowning as if looking at something he had never seen before. He sees it, too, now. "You can do it, Rand," Perrin said. "You can."

"ɪt wɪl hɛlp," vɛɹɪn sɛd, "ɪf jə doʊn tɛl ɛvɹiwʌn wʌt jə ɑɹ nɑt. pipəl si wʌt ðeɪ ɪkspɛk tə si. bɪɑn ðæt, lʊk əm ɪn ði aɪ ən spik fɝmli. ðə weɪ juv bɪn tɔkɪŋ tə mi," ʃi æɾəd dʒɹaɪli, ən ɹændz tʃiks kʌlɝd, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt dʒɹɑp ɪz aɪz. "ɪt dʌzn mæɾɝ wʌt jə seɪ. ðəl ətʃɹɪbjuɾ ɛniθɪŋ aʊɾ ə pleɪs tə jəɹ biɪŋ ən aʊtləndɝ. ɪɾəl ɔlsoʊ hɛlp ɪf jə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə weɪ jə bɪheɪv bɪfɔɹ ði æmɪɝlɪn. ɪf jə ɑɹ ðəɾ ɛɹəɡənt, ðəl bɪliv jə ɑɹ ə lɔɹɾ ɪf jə wɛɹ ɹæɡz." mæt snɪkɝd.

"It will help," Verin said, "if you don't tell everyone what you are not. People see what they expect to see. Beyond that, look them in the eye and speak firmly. The way you have been talking to me," she added dryly, and Rand's cheeks colored, but he did not drop his eyes. "It doesn't matter what you say. They will attribute anything out of place to your being an outlander. It will also help if you remember the way you behaved before the Amyrlin. If you are that arrogant, they will believe you are a lord if you wear rags." Mat snickered.

ɹænd θɹu ʌp ɪz hænz. "ɔl ɹaɪt. əl də ɪt. bʌɾ aɪ stɪl θɪŋk ðəl noʊ faɪv mɪnəts æftɝ aɪ oʊpən maɪ maʊθ. wɛn?"

Rand threw up his hands. "All right. I'll do it. But I still think they will know five minutes after I open my mouth. When?"

"bɑɹθeɪnz əz æsk jə fəɹ faɪv dɪfɹən deɪts, ən wʌn ɪz təmɑɹoʊ naɪt."

"Barthanes has asked you for five different dates, and one is tomorrow night."

"təmɑɹoʊ!" ɪŋtʃɹ ɪksploʊɾəd. "ðə hɔɹn kəd bi fɪfti maɪlz daʊnɹɪvɝ baɪ təmɑɹoʊ naɪt, əɹ - "

"Tomorrow!" Ingtar exploded. "The Horn could be fifty miles downriver by tomorrow night, or - "

vɛɹɪn kʌɾ ɪm ɔf. "ənoʊ ən jəɹ soʊlʒɝz kən wɑtʃ ðə mænɝ. ɪf ðeɪ tʃɹaɪ tə teɪk ðə hɔɹn ɛniwɛɹ, wi kən izəli fɑloʊ, ən pɝhæps ɹɪtʃɹiv ɪt mɔɹ izəli ðən fɹəm ɪnsaɪd bɑɹθeɪnzəz wɔlz."

Verin cut him off. "Uno and your soldiers can watch the manor. If they try to take the Horn anywhere, we can easily follow, and perhaps retrieve it more easily than from inside Barthanes's walls."

"pɝhæps soʊ," ɪŋtʃɹ əɡɹid ɡɹʌdʒɪŋli. "aɪ dʒʌs də nɑt laɪk tə weɪt, naʊ ðət ðə hɔɹn ɪz ɔlmoʊst ɪn maɪ hænz. əl əv ɪt. aɪ mʌst! aɪ mʌst!"

"Perhaps so," Ingtar agreed grudgingly. "I just do not like to wait, now that the Horn is almost in my hands. I will have it. I must! I must!"

hʊɹɪn stɛɹɾ ət hɪm. "bʌt, lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹ, ðəɾ ɪzən ðə weɪ. wʌt hæpənz, hæpənz, ən wʌɾ ɪz mɛn tə bi, wɪl - " ɪŋtʃɹz ɡlɛɹ kʌɾ ɪm ɔf, ðoʊ hi stɪl mʌɾɝd ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ, "ɪɾ ɪzən ðə weɪ, tɔkɪŋ ʌv 'mʌst.' "

Hurin stared at him. "But, Lord Ingtar, that isn't the way. What happens, happens, and what is meant to be, will - " Ingtar's glare cut him off, though he still muttered under his breath, "It isn't the way, talking of 'must.' "

ɪŋtʃɹ tɝn bæk tə vɛɹɪn stɪfli. "vɛɹɪn sədaɪ, kɛɹhinɪn ɑɹ vɛɹi stʃɹɪkt ɪn ðɛɹ pɹoʊɾəkɑl. ɪf ɹænd dʌz nɑt sɛn ə ɹɪplaɪ, bɑɹθeɪnz meɪ bi soʊ ɪnsʌltɪd hɪl nɑt lɛɾ əs ɪn, ivən wɪð ðət pɑɹtʃmən ɪn əɹ hænz. bʌɾ ɪf ɹænd dʌz . . . wɛl, feɪn, ət list, noʊz hɪm. wi kəd bi wɔɹnɪŋ əm tə sɛɾ ə tʃɹæp."

Ingtar turned back to Verin stiffly. "Verin Sedai, Cairhienin are very strict in their protocol. If Rand does not send a reply, Barthanes may be so insulted he will not let us in, even with that parchment in our hands. But if Rand does . . . well, Fain, at least, knows him. We could be warning them to set a trap."

"wi wɪl sɝpɹaɪz ðɛm." hɝ bɹif smaɪl wɑz nɑt plɛzənt. "bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk bɑɹθeɪnz wɪl wɑnə si ɹænd ɪn ɛni keɪs. dɑɹkfɹɛn əɹ nɑt, aɪ daʊt hiz ɡɪvən ʌp plɑts əɡɛns ðə θɹoʊn. ɹænd, hi sɛz jə tʊk ən ɪntʃɹəst ɪn wʌn ə ðə kɪŋz pɹɑdʒɛks, bʌɾ i dʌzn seɪ wʌt. wʌt dʌz i min?"

"We will surprise them." Her brief smile was not pleasant. "But I think Barthanes will want to see Rand in any case. Darkfriend or not, I doubt he has given up plots against the throne. Rand, he says you took an interest in one of the King's projects, but he doesn't say what. What does he mean?"

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ," ɹænd sɛd sloʊli. "aɪ hævən dʌn ɛniθɪŋ əɾ ɔl sɪns aɪ ɝaɪvd. weɪt. meɪbi hi minz ðə stætʃu. wi keɪm θɹu ə vɪlədʒ wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ dɪɡɪŋ ʌp ə hjudʒ stætʃu. fɹəm ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz, ðeɪ sɛd. ðə kɪŋ minz tə muv ɪt tə kɛɹhin, ðoʊ aɪ doʊnt noʊ haʊ hi kən muv sʌmθɪŋ ðət bɪɡ. bʌɾ ɔl aɪ dɪd wɑz æsk wʌɾ ɪt wɑz."

"I don't know," Rand said slowly. "I haven't done anything at all since I arrived. Wait. Maybe he means the statue. We came through a village where they were digging up a huge statue. From the Age of Legends, they said. The King means to move it to Cairhien, though I don't know how he can move something that big. But all I did was ask what it was."

"wi pæst ɪɾ ɪn ðə deɪ, ən dɪd nɑt stɑp tə æsk kwɛstʃənz." vɛɹɪn lɛt ði ɪnvɪteɪʃən fɔl ɪn əɹ læp. "nɑɾ ə waɪz θɪŋ fəɹ ɡɔlʒɹiən tə du, pɝhæps, ənɝθəŋ ðæt. nɑt ðət ðəɹ ɪz ɛni ɹil deɪnʒɝ, bʌɾ ɪts nɛvɝ waɪz fəɹ ðoʊz u doʊnt noʊ wʌt ðeɪ ɑɹ duɪŋ tə mɛɾəl wɪð θɪŋz fɹəm ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz."

"We passed it in the day, and did not stop to ask questions." Verin let the invitation fall in her lap. "Not a wise thing for Galldrian to do, perhaps, unearthing that. Not that there is any real danger, but it is never wise for those who don't know what they are doing to meddle with things from the Age of Legends."

"wʌɾ ɪz ɪt?" ɹænd æskt.

"What is it?" Rand asked.

"ə sɑŋɡɹil." ʃi saʊndəɾ əz ɪf ɪt wɝ ɹɪli nɑt vɛɹi ɪmpɔɹɾənt, bʌt pɛɹɪn sʌɾənli hæd ðə filɪŋ ðə tu ʌv əm hæɾ ɛntɝɾ ə pɹaɪvət kɑnvɝseɪʃən, seɪɪŋ θɪŋz noʊ wʌn ɛls kəd hɪɹ. "wʌn ʌv ə pɛɹ, ðə tu lɑɹdʒəst ɛvɝ meɪd, ðət wi noʊ ʌv. ən ən ɑd pɛɹ, əz wɛl. wʌn, stɪl bɛɹiɾ ɑn tʃɹɛmælkɪŋ, kən oʊnli bi juz baɪ ə wʊmən. ðɪs wʌn kən oʊnli bi juz baɪ ə mæn. ðeɪ wɝ meɪd dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ə ðə paʊɝz, tə bi ə wɛpən, bʌɾ ɪf ðəɹ ɪz ɛniθɪŋ tə bi θæŋkfəl fəɹ ɪn ði ɛn ə ðəɾ eɪdʒ əɹ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld, ɪts ðət ði ɛn keɪm bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ kəd bi juzd. təɡɛðɝ, ðeɪ maɪt wɛl bi paʊɝfəl ɪnʌf tə bɹeɪk ðə wɝld əɡɛn, pɝhæps ivən wɝs ðən ðə fɝs bɹeɪkɪŋ."

"A sa'angreal." She sounded as if it were really not very important, but Perrin suddenly had the feeling the two of them had entered a private conversation, saying things no one else could hear. "One of a pair, the two largest ever made, that we know of. And an odd pair, as well. One, still buried on Tremalking, can only be used by a woman. This one can only be used by a man. They were made during the War of the Powers, to be a weapon, but if there is anything to be thankful for in the end of that Age or the Breaking of the World, it is that the end came before they could be used. Together, they might well be powerful enough to Break the World again, perhaps even worse than the first Breaking."

pɛɹɪnz hænz taɪɾənd tə nɑts. hi əvɔɪɾəd lʊkɪŋ dɝɛkli ət ɹænd, bʌɾ ivən fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz aɪ hi kəd si ə waɪtnəs ɝaʊn ɹændz maʊθ. hi θɔt ɹænd maɪt bi əfɹeɪd, ən i dɪd nɑt bleɪm ɪm ə bɪt.

Perrin's hands tightened to knots. He avoided looking directly at Rand, but even from the corner of his eye he could see a whiteness around Rand's mouth. He thought Rand might be afraid, and he did not blame him a bit.

ɪŋtʃɹ lʊkt ʃeɪkən, əz wɛl i maɪt. "ðæt θɪŋ ʃəd bi bɛɹiɾ əɡɛn, ən əz dipli əz ðeɪ kən paɪl dɝɾ ən stoʊn. wʌt wʊɾə hæpən ɪf lɑɡən hæd faʊn ɪt? əɹ ɛni ɹɛtʃɪd mæn u kən tʃænəl, lɛɾ əloʊn wʌn kleɪmɪŋ hiz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. vɛɹɪn sədaɪ, jə mʌst wɔɹn ɡɔlʒɹiən wʌt hiz duɪŋ."

Ingtar looked shaken, as well he might. "That thing should be buried again, and as deeply as they can pile dirt and stone. What would have happened if Logain had found it? Or any wretched man who can channel, let alone one claiming he's the Dragon Reborn. Verin Sedai, you must warn Galldrian what he's doing."

"wʌt? oʊ, ðəɹ ɪz noʊ nid fəɹ ðæt, aɪ θɪŋk. ðə tu mʌs bi juzd ɪn junəsən tə hændəl ɪnʌf ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ tə bɹeɪk ðə wɝld - ðət wɑz ðə weɪ ɪn ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz; ə mæn ən ə wʊmən wɝkɪŋ təɡɛðɝ wɝ ɔlweɪz tɛn taɪmz əz stʃɹɔŋ əz ðeɪ wɝ əpɑɹt - ən wʌɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ tədeɪ wəɾ eɪɾ ə mæn ɪn tʃænəlɪŋ? wʌn baɪ ɪtsɛlf ɪz paʊɝfəl ɪnʌf, bʌɾ aɪ kən θɪŋk ə fju wɪmən stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə sɝvaɪv ðə floʊ θɹu ðə wʌn ɑn tʃɹɛmælkɪŋ. ði æmɪɝlɪn, ʌv kɔɹs. mɔɪɹeɪn, ən ɪleɪɾə. pɝhæps wʌn əɹ tu ʌðɝz. ən θɹi stɪl ɪn tʃɹeɪnɪŋ. əz fəɹ lɑɡən, ɪt wʊɾə teɪkən ɔl ɪz stʃɹɛŋkθ sɪmpli tə kip fɹəm biɪŋ bɝn tə ə sɪndɝ, wɪð nʌθɪŋ lɛft fəɹ duɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ. noʊ, ɪŋtʃɹ, aɪ doʊn θɪŋk jə nid wɝi. ət list, nɑɾ əntɪl ðə ɹil dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn pɹoʊkleɪmz hɪmsɛlf, ən ðən wɪl ɔl əv ɪnʌf tə wɝi əbaʊɾ əz ɪɾ ɪz. lɛɾ əs wɝi naʊ əbaʊt wʌt wi ʃæl də wən wəɹ ɪnsaɪd bɑɹθeɪnzəz mænɝ."

"What? Oh, there is no need for that, I think. The two must be used in unison to handle enough of the One Power to Break the World - that was the way in the Age of Legends; a man and a woman working together were always ten times as strong as they were apart - and what Aes Sedai today would aid a man in channeling? One by itself is powerful enough, but I can think of few women strong enough to survive the flow through the one on Tremalking. The Amyrlin, of course. Moiraine, and Elaida. Perhaps one or two others. And three still in training. As for Logain, it would have taken all his strength simply to keep from being burned to a cinder, with nothing left for doing anything. No, Ingtar, I don't think you need worry. At least, not until the real Dragon Reborn proclaims himself, and then we will all have enough to worry about as it is. Let us worry now about what we shall do when we are inside Barthanes's manor."

ʃi wɑz tɔkɪŋ tə ɹænd. pɛɹɪn nu ɪt, ən fɹəm ðə kwizi lʊk ɪn mæts aɪ, hi dɪd, tu. ivən lɔɪəl ʃɪftəd nɝvəsli ɪn ɪz tʃɛɹ. oʊ, laɪt, ɹænd, pɛɹɪn θɔt. laɪt, doʊn lɛɾ əɹ juz ju.

She was talking to Rand. Perrin knew it, and from the queasy look in Mat's eye, he did, too. Even Loial shifted nervously in his chair. Oh, Light, Rand, Perrin thought. Light, don't let her use you.

ɹændz hænz wɝ pɹɛsɪŋ ðə teɪbəltɑp soʊ hɑɹd ðəɾ ɪz nʌkəlz wɝ waɪt, bʌɾ ɪz vɔɪs wɑz stɛɾi. hɪz aɪz nɛvɝ lɛf ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. "fɝst wɪv tə teɪk bæk ðə hɔɹn, ən ðə dæɡɝ. ən ðən ɪts dʌn, vɛɹɪn. ðən ɪts dʌn."

Rand's hands were pressing the tabletop so hard that his knuckles were white, but his voice was steady. His eyes never left the Aes Sedai. "First we have to take back the Horn, and the dagger. And then it is done, Verin. Then it is done."

wɑtʃɪŋ vɛɹɪnz smaɪl, smɔl ən mɪstɪɹiəs, pɛɹɪn fɛlt ə tʃɪl. hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ɹænd nu hæf wʌɾ i θɔɾ i dɪd. nɑt hæf.

Watching Verin's smile, small and mysterious, Perrin felt a chill. He did not think Rand knew half what he thought he did. Not half.


tʃæptɝ θɝɾitu


CHAPTER 32

deɪnʒɝəs wɝdz


Dangerous Words

lɔɹd bɑɹθeɪnzəz mænɝ kɹaʊtʃt laɪk ə hjudʒ toʊɾ ɪn ðə naɪt, kʌvɝɪŋ əz mʌtʃ ɡɹaʊn əz ə fɔɹtʃɹəs, wɪð ɔl ɪts wɔlz ən aʊtbɪldɪŋz. ɪt wɑz noʊ fɔɹtʃɹəs, ðoʊ, wɪð tɔl wɪndoʊz ɛvɹiwɛɹ, ən laɪts, ən ðə saʊnz ə mjuzɪk ən læftɝ dʒɹɪftɪŋ aʊt, jɛt ɹænd sɔ ɡɑɹdz muvɪŋ ɑn ðə taʊɝ tɑps ən əlɔŋ ðə ɹufwɔks, ən nʌn ə ðə wɪndoʊz wɝ kloʊs tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. hi ɡɑt daʊn fɹəm ɹɛdz bæk ən smuðd ɪz koʊt, ədʒʌstəɾ ɪz sɔɹd bɛlt. ði ʌðɝz dɪsmaʊntɪɾ ɝaʊn hɪm, ət ðə fʊɾ ə bɹɔd, waɪtstoʊn stɛɹz liɾɪŋ ʌp tə ðə waɪd, hɛvəli kɑɹv dɔɹz ə ðə mænɝ.

Lord Barthanes's manor crouched like a huge toad in the night, covering as much ground as a fortress, with all its walls and outbuildings. It was no fortress, though, with tall windows everywhere, and lights, and the sounds of music and laughter drifting out, yet Rand saw guards moving on the tower tops and along the roofwalks, and none of the windows were close to the ground. He got down from Red's back and smoothed his coat, adjusted his sword belt. The others dismounted around him, at the foot of broad, whitestone stairs leading up to the wide, heavily carved doors of the manor.

tɛn ʃaɪnɝənz, ʌndɝ ənoʊ, meɪɾ ən ɛskɔɹt. ðə wʌn-aɪd mæn ɪkstʃeɪnʒd smɔl nɑdz wɪð ɪŋtʃɹ bɪfɔɹ teɪkɪŋ ɪz mɛn tə dʒɔɪn ði ʌðɝ ɛskɔɹts, wɛɹ eɪl hæd bɪn pɹəvaɪɾəd ən ə hoʊl ɑks wɑz ɹoʊstɪŋ ɑn ə spɪt baɪ ə bɪɡ faɪɝ.

Ten Shienarans, under Uno, made an escort. The one-eyed man exchanged small nods with Ingtar before taking his men to join the other escorts, where ale had been provided and a whole ox was roasting on a spit by a big fire.

ði ʌðɝ tɛn ʃaɪnɝənz hæd bɪn lɛf bɪhaɪnd, əlɔŋ wɪð pɛɹɪn. ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðɛm hæd tə bi ðəɹ fəɹ ə pɝpəs, vɛɹɪn hæd sɛd, ən pɛɹɪn hæd noʊ pɝpəs tə sɝv ðɪs naɪt. ən ɛskɔɹt wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi fəɹ dɪɡnəɾi ɪn kɛɹhinɪn aɪz, bʌt mɔɹ ðən tɛn wəd sim səspɪʃəs. ɹænd wɑz ðəɹ kəz i hæd ɹəsiv ði ɪnvɪteɪʃən. ɪŋtʃɹ hæd kʌm tə lɛn ðə pɹɛstiʒ ə hɪz taɪɾəl, waɪl lɔɪəl wɑz ðəɹ kəz oʊɡiɝ wɝ sɔɾ æftɝ ɪn ði ʌpɝ ɹitʃəz ə ðə kɛɹhinɪn noʊbɪləɾi. hʊɹɪn pɹitɛndəd tə bi ɪŋtʃɹz bɑdaɪsɝvənt. hɪz tʃɹu pɝpəs wɑz tə snɪf aʊt ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz ən tʃɹɑləks ɪf i kʊd; ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ ʃəd nɑt bi fɑɹ fɹəm ðɛm. mæt, stɪl ɡɹʌmbəlɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt, wɑz pɹitɛndɪŋ tə bi ɹændz sɝvənt, sɪns i kəd fil ðə dæɡɝ wən ɪt wɑz kloʊs. ɪf hʊɹɪn feɪld, pɝhæps i kəd faɪn ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz.

The other ten Shienarans had been left behind, along with Perrin. Every one of them had to be there for a purpose, Verin had said, and Perrin had no purpose to serve this night. An escort was necessary for dignity in Cairhienin eyes, but more than ten would seem suspicious. Rand was there because he had received the invitation. Ingtar had come to lend the prestige of his title, while Loial was there because Ogier were sought after in the upper reaches of the Cairhienin nobility. Hurin pretended to be Ingtar's bodyservant. His true purpose was to sniff out the Darkfriends and Trollocs if he could; the Horn of Valere should not be far from them. Mat, still grumbling about it, was pretending to be Rand's servant, since he could feel the dagger when it was close. If Hurin failed, perhaps he could find the Darkfriends.

wən ɹænd hæɾ æsk vɛɹɪn waɪ ʃi wɑz ðɛɹ, ʃi hæɾ oʊnli smaɪld ən sɛd, "tə kip ðə ɹɛst ə jə aʊɾ ə tʃɹʌbəl."

When Rand had asked Verin why she was there, she had only smiled and said, "To keep the rest of you out of trouble."

əz ðeɪ maʊntəd ðə stɛɹz, mæt mʌɾɝd, "aɪ stɪl doʊn si waɪ aɪ hæv tə bi ə sɝvənt." hi ən hʊɹɪn fɑloʊd bɪhaɪn ði ʌðɝz. "bɝn mi, ɪf ɹænd kən bi ə lɔɹd, aɪ kən pʊɾ ɑn ə fænsi koʊt, tu."

As they mounted the stairs, Mat muttered, "I still don't see why I have to be a servant." He and Hurin followed behind the others. "Burn me, if Rand can be a lord, I can put on a fancy coat, too."

"ə sɝvənt," vɛɹɪn sɛd wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ bæk ət hɪm, "kæn ɡoʊ mɛni pleɪsəz ənʌðɝ mæn kænɑt, ən mɛni noʊbəlz wɪl nɑɾ ivən si hɪm. jə ən hʊɹɪn əv jəɹ tæsks."

"A servant," Verin said without looking back at him, "can go many places another man cannot, and many nobles will not even see him. You and Hurin have your tasks."

"bi kwaɪət naʊ, mæt," ɪŋtʃɹ pʊɾ ɪn, "ənlɛs jə wɑnə ɡɪv əs əweɪ." ðeɪ wɝ əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ ðə dɔɹz, wɛɹ hæf ə dʌzən ɡɑɹdz stʊd wɪð ðə tʃɹi ən kɹaʊn ə haʊs dəmədʒɹɾ ɑn ðɛɹ tʃɛsts, ən ən ikwəl nʌmbɝ ə mɛn ɪn dɑɹk ɡɹin lɪvɝi wɪð tʃɹi ən kɹaʊn ɑn ðə sliv.

"Be quiet now, Mat," Ingtar put in, "unless you want to give us away." They were approaching the doors, where half a dozen guards stood with the Tree and Crown of House Damodred on their chests, and an equal number of men in dark green livery with Tree and Crown on the sleeve.

teɪkɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ, ɹænd pɹɑfɝd ði ɪnvɪteɪʃən. "aɪ æm lɔɹd ɹænd ə haʊs ælθɹ," hi sɛɾ ɔl ɪn ə ɹʌʃ, tə ɡɛɾ ɪɾ oʊvɝ wɪð. "æn ðiz ɑɹ maɪ ɡɛsts. vɛɹɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌv ðə bɹaʊn ədʒɑ. lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹ ə haʊs ʃɪnoʊwə, ɪn ʃaɪnɝ. lɔɪəl, sʌn ʌv ɑɹən sʌn ə hɑlən, fɹəm stɛɾɪŋ ʃæŋktaɪ." lɔɪəl hæɾ æsk ðəɾ ɪz stɛɾɪŋ bi lɛft aʊɾ ʌv ɪt, bʌt vɛɹɪn ɪnsɪstəd ðeɪ niɾəd ɛvɹi bɪɾ ə fɔɹmæləɾi ðeɪ kəɾ ɔfɝ.

Taking a deep breath, Rand proffered the invitation. "I am Lord Rand of House al'Thor," he said all in a rush, to get it over with. "And these are my guests. Verin Aes Sedai of the Brown Ajah. Lord Ingtar of House Shinowa, in Shienar. Loial, son of Arent son of Halan, from Stedding Shangtai." Loial had asked that his stedding be left out of it, but Verin insisted they needed every bit of formality they could offer.

ðə sɝvən u hæd ɹitʃt fəɹ ði ɪnvɪteɪʃən wɪð ə pɝfʌŋktɝi baʊ ɡeɪv ə lɪɾəl dʒɝk əɾ itʃ ədɪʃənəl neɪm; hɪz aɪz pɑpt ət vɛɹɪnz. ɪn ə stʃɹæŋɡəl vɔɪs i sɛd, "bi wɛlkəm ɪn haʊs dəmədʒɹd, maɪ lɔɹdz. bi wɛlkəm, ɛɛs sədaɪ. bi wɛlkəm, fɹɛn oʊɡiɝ." hi weɪv ði ʌðɝ sɝvəns tə oʊpən ðə dɔɹz waɪd, ən baʊd ɹænd ən ði ʌðɝz ɪnsaɪd, wɛɹ i hɝidli pæs ði ɪnvɪteɪʃən tə ənʌðɝ lɪvɹid mæn ən wɪspɝɾ ɪn ɪz ɪɹ.

The servant who had reached for the invitation with a perfunctory bow gave a little jerk at each additional name; his eyes popped at Verin's. In a strangled voice he said, "Be welcome in House Damodred, my lords. Be welcome, Aes Sedai. Be welcome, friend Ogier." He waved the other servants to open the doors wide, and bowed Rand and the others inside, where he hurriedly passed the invitation to another liveried man and whispered in his ear.

ðɪs mæn hæd ðə tʃɹi ən kɹaʊn lɑɹdʒ ɑn ðə tʃɛst ə hɪz ɡɹin koʊt. "ɛɛs sədaɪ," hi sɛd, juzɪŋ ɪz lɔŋ stæf tə meɪk ə baʊ, ɔlmoʊs bɛndɪŋ ɪz hɛd tə hɪz niz, tə itʃ ə ðɛm ɪn tɝn. "maɪ lɔɹdz. fɹɛn oʊɡiɝ. aɪm kɔld æʃɪn. pliz tə fɑloʊ mi."

This man had the Tree and Crown large on the chest of his green coat. "Aes Sedai," he said, using his long staff to make a bow, almost bending his head to his knees, to each of them in turn. "My lords. Friend Ogier. I am called Ashin. Please to follow me."

ði aʊɾɝ hɔl hɛld oʊnli sɝvəns, bʌɾ æʃɪn lɛɾ əm tə ə ɡɹeɪt ɹum fɪld wɪð noʊbəlz, wɪð ə dʒʌɡəlɝ pɝfɔɹmɪŋ ət wʌn ɛn ən tʌmblɝz ət ði ʌðɝ. vɔɪsəz ən mjuzɪk kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ɛlswɛɹ sɛd ðiz wɝ nɑt ði oʊnli ɡɛsts, əɹ ði oʊnli ɛntɝteɪnməns. ðə noʊbəlz stʊɾ ɪn tuz, ən θɹiz ən fɔɹz, səmtaɪmz mɛn ən wɪmən təɡɛðɝ, səmtaɪmz oʊnli wʌn əɹ ði ʌðɝ, ɔlweɪz wɪð kɛɹfəl speɪs bɪtwin soʊ noʊ wʌn kəɾ oʊvɝhɪɹ wʌt wɑz sɛd. ðə ɡɛsts wɔɹ ðə dɑɹk kɛɹhinɪn kʌlɝz, itʃ wɪð bɹaɪt stʃɹaɪps ət lis hæfweɪ daʊn ɪz əɹ əɹ tʃɛst, ən səm hæɾ əm ɔl ðə weɪ tə ðɛɹ weɪsts. ðə wɪmən hæd ðɛɹ hɛɹ paɪl haɪ ɪn ɪlæbɹət taʊɝz ə kɝlz, ɛvɹi wʌn dɪfɹənt, ən ðɛɹ dɑɹk skɝts wɝ soʊ waɪd ðeɪ wʊɾə hæd tə tɝn saɪdweɪz tə pæs θɹu ɛni dɔɹweɪ nɛɹoʊɝ ðən ðoʊz ə ðə mænɝ. nʌn ə ðə mɛn hæd ðə ʃeɪv hɛdz ə soʊlʒɝz - ðeɪ ɔl wɔɹ dɑɹk vɛlvət hæts oʊvɝ lɔŋ hɛɹ, səm ʃeɪp laɪk bɛlz, ʌðɝz flæt - ən əz wɪð ðə wɪmən, leɪs ɹʌfəlz laɪk dɑɹk aɪvɝi ɔlmoʊs hɪd ðɛɹ hænz.

The outer hall held only servants, but Ashin led them to a great room filled with nobles, with a juggler performing at one end and tumblers at the other. Voices and music coming from elsewhere said these were not the only guests, or the only entertainments. The nobles stood in twos, and threes and fours, sometimes men and women together, sometimes only one or the other, always with careful space between so no one could overhear what was said. The guests wore the dark Cairhienin colors, each with bright stripes at least halfway down his or her chest, and some had them all the way to their waists. The women had their hair piled high in elaborate towers of curls, every one different, and their dark skirts were so wide they would have had to turn sideways to pass through any doorway narrower than those of the manor. None of the men had the shaved heads of soldiers - they all wore dark velvet hats over long hair, some shaped like bells, others flat - and as with the women, lace ruffles like dark ivory almost hid their hands.

æʃɪn ɹæpt ɪz stæf ən ənaʊnst əm ɪn ə laʊd vɔɪs, vɛɹɪn fɝst.

Ashin rapped his staff and announced them in a loud voice, Verin first.

ðeɪ dʒɹu ɛvɹi aɪ. vɛɹɪn wɔɹ əɹ bɹaʊn-fɹɪnd ʃɔl, ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɪn ɡɹeɪp vaɪnz; ði ənaʊnsmən ʌv ən ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛn ə mɝmɝ θɹu ðə lɔɹdz ən leɪɾiz, ən meɪd ðə dʒʌɡəlɝ dʒɹɑp wʌn ə hɪz hups, ðoʊ noʊ wʌn wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ ɪm ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. lɔɪəl ɹəsivd ɔlmoʊst əz mɛni lʊks, ivən bɪfɔɹ æʃɪn spoʊk ɪz neɪm. dɪspaɪt ðə sɪlvɝ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi ɑn kɑlɝ ən slivz, ði ʌðɝwaɪz ʌnɹiliv blæk ə ɹændz koʊt meɪɾ ɪm sim ɔlmoʊst stɑɹk bɪsaɪd ðə kɛɹhinɪn, ən ɪz ən ɪŋtʃɹz sɔɹdz dʒɹu mɛni ɡlænsɪz. nʌn ə ðə lɔɹdz əpɪɹd tə bi ɑɹmd. ɹænd hɝd ðə wɝdz "hɛɹən-mɑɹk bleɪd" mɔɹ ðən wʌns. səm ə ðə ɡlænsɪz i wɑz ɹəsivɪŋ lʊk laɪk fɹaʊnz; hi səspɛktəd ðeɪ keɪm fɹəm mɛn i hæɾ ɪnsʌltɪd baɪ bɝnɪŋ ðɛɹ ɪnvɪteɪʃənz.

They drew every eye. Verin wore her brown-fringed shawl, embroidered in grape vines; the announcement of an Aes Sedai sent a murmur through the lords and ladies, and made the juggler drop one of his hoops, though no one was watching him any longer. Loial received almost as many looks, even before Ashin spoke his name. Despite the silver embroidery on collar and sleeves, the otherwise unrelieved black of Rand's coat made him seem almost stark beside the Cairhienin, and his and Ingtar's swords drew many glances. None of the lords appeared to be armed. Rand heard the words "heron-mark blade" more than once. Some of the glances he was receiving looked like frowns; he suspected they came from men he had insulted by burning their invitations.

ə slɪm, hænsəm mæn əpɹoʊtʃt. hi hæd lɔŋ, ɡɹeɪɪŋ hɛɹ, ən mʌltəhud stʃɹaɪps kɹɔs ðə fɹʌn ə hɪz dip ɡɹeɪ koʊt fɹəm ɪz nɛk ɔlmoʊs tə ðə hɛm dʒʌst əbʌv ɪz niz. hi wɑz ɪkstʃɹimli tɔl fəɹ ə kɛɹhinɪn, noʊ mɔɹ ðən hæf ə hɛd ʃɔɹɾɝ ðən ɹænd, ən i hæɾ ə weɪ ʌv stændɪŋ ðət meɪɾ ɪm sim ivən tɔlɝ, wɪð ɪz tʃɪn ʌp soʊ hi sim tə bi lʊkɪŋ daʊn əɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls. hɪz aɪz wɝ blæk pɛbəlz. hi lʊkt wɛɹəli ət vɛɹɪn, ðoʊ.

A slim, handsome man approached. He had long, graying hair, and multihued stripes crossed the front of his deep gray coat from his neck almost to the hem just above his knees. He was extremely tall for a Cairhienin, no more than half a head shorter than Rand, and he had a way of standing that made him seem even taller, with his chin up so he seemed to be looking down at everyone else. His eyes were black pebbles. He looked warily at Verin, though.

"ɡɹeɪs ɑnɝz mi wɪð jəɹ pɹɛzəns, ɛɛs sədaɪ." bɑɹθeɪnz dəmədʒɹdz vɔɪs wɑz dip ən ʃʊɹ. hɪz ɡeɪz swɛpt əkɹɔs ði ʌðɝz. "aɪ dɪd nɑɾ ɪkspɛk soʊ dɪstɪŋɡwɪʃt ə kʌmpəni. lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹ. fɹɛn oʊɡiɝ." hɪz baʊ tə itʃ wɑz lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən ə nɑɾ ə ðə hɛd; bɑɹθeɪnz nu ɪɡzækli haʊ paʊɝfəl i wɑz. "æn ju, maɪ jʌŋ lɔɹd ɹænd. jə ɪksaɪt mʌtʃ kɑmɛn ɪn ðə sɪɾi, ən ɪn ðə haʊsəz. pɝhæps wɪl əv ə tʃæns tə tɔk ðɪs naɪt." hɪz toʊn sɛd ðəɾ i wəd nɑt mɪs ɪɾ ɪf ðə tʃæns nɛvɝ keɪm, ðəɾ i hæd nɑt bɪn ɪksaɪɾəd tə ɛni kɑmɛnt, bʌɾ ɪz aɪz slɪɾ ə fɹækʃən bɪfɔɹ i kɑt ðɛm, tə ɪŋtʃɹ ən lɔɪəl, ən tə vɛɹɪn. "bi wɛlkəm." hi lɛt hɪmsɛlf bi dʒɹɔn əweɪ baɪ ə hænsəm wʊmən u leɪɾ ə bɛɹɪn hæn bɛɹiɾ ɪn leɪs ɑn ɪz ɑɹm, bʌɾ ɪz ɡeɪz dʒɹɪftəd bæk tə ɹænd əz i wɔkt əweɪ.

"Grace honors me with your presence, Aes Sedai." Barthanes Damodred's voice was deep and sure. His gaze swept across the others. "I did not expect so distinguished a company. Lord Ingtar. Friend Ogier." His bow to each was little more than a nod of the head; Barthanes knew exactly how powerful he was. "And you, my young Lord Rand. You excite much comment in the city, and in the Houses. Perhaps we will have a chance to talk this night." His tone said that he would not miss it if the chance never came, that he had not been excited to any comment, but his eyes slid a fraction before he caught them, to Ingtar and Loial, and to Verin. "Be welcome." He let himself be drawn away by a handsome woman who laid a beringed hand buried in lace on his arm, but his gaze drifted back to Rand as he walked away.

ðə mɝmɝ ə kɑnvɝseɪʃən pɪkt ʌp wʌns mɔɹ, ən ðə dʒʌɡəlɝ spʌn ɪz hups əɡɛn ɪn ə nɛɹoʊ lup ðəɾ ɔlmoʊst ɹitʃt ðə wɝk plæstɝ silɪŋ, ə ɡʊd fɔɹ spænz ʌp. ðə tʌmblɝz hæd nɛvɝ stɑpt; ə wʊmən lɛpt ɪndə ði ɛɹ fɹəm ðə kʌp hænz ʌv wʌn ə hɝ kəmpeɪtʃɹiəts, hɝ ɔɪl skɪn ʃaɪnɪŋ ɪn ðə laɪɾ ʌv ə hʌnʒɹəd læmps əz ʃi spʌn, ən lændəɾ ɑn əɹ fiɾ ɑn ðə hænz ʌv ə mæn u wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi stændɪŋ ətɑp ənʌðɝz ʃoʊldɝz. hi lɪftəɾ əɹ ʌp ɑn aʊtstʃɹɛtʃt ɑɹmz əz ðə mæn bɪloʊ ɹeɪzd ɪm ɪn ðə seɪm weɪ, ən ʃi spɹɛɾ əɹ ɑɹmz əz ɪf fəɹ əplɔz. nʌn ə ðə kɛɹhinɪn sim tə noʊɾəs.

The murmur of conversation picked up once more, and the juggler spun his hoops again in a narrow loop that almost reached the worked plaster ceiling, a good four spans up. The tumblers had never stopped; a woman leaped into the air from the cupped hands of one of her compatriots, her oiled skin shining in the light of a hundred lamps as she spun, and landed on her feet on the hands of a man who was already standing atop another's shoulders. He lifted her up on outstretched arms as the man below raised him in the same way, and she spread her arms as if for applause. None of the Cairhienin seemed to notice.

vɛɹɪn ən ɪŋtʃɹ dʒɹɪftəɾ ɪndə ðə kɹaʊd. ðə ʃaɪnɝən ɹəsivd ə fju wɛɹi lʊks; səm lʊkt ət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪð waɪɾ aɪz, ʌðɝz wɪð ðə wɝid fɹaʊnz ə ðoʊz faɪndɪŋ ə ɹæbɪd wʊlf wɪðɪn ɑɹmz ɹitʃ. ðə læɾɝ keɪm fɹəm mɛn mɔɹ ɔfən ðən wɪmən, ən səm ə ðə wɪmən spoʊk tə hɝ.

Verin and Ingtar drifted into the crowd. The Shienaran received a few wary looks; some looked at the Aes Sedai with wide eyes, others with the worried frowns of those finding a rabid wolf within arm's reach. The latter came from men more often than women, and some of the women spoke to her.

ɹænd ɹilaɪz ðət mæt ən hʊɹɪn hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi dɪsəpɪɹd tə ðə kɪtʃənz, wɛɹ ɔl ðə sɝvəns u hæd kʌm wɪð ðə ɡɛsts wəd bi ɡæðɝɪŋ əntɪl sɛn fɔɹ. hi hoʊp ðeɪ wəd nɑɾ əv tʃɹʌbəl snikɪŋ əweɪ.

Rand realized that Mat and Hurin had already disappeared to the kitchens, where all the servants who had come with the guests would be gathering until sent for. He hoped they would not have trouble sneaking away.

lɔɪəl bɛn daʊn tə spik fəɹ ɪz ɪɹ əloʊn. "ɹænd, ðəɹ ɪz ə weɪɡeɪt nɪɹbaɪ. aɪ kən fil ɪt."

Loial bent down to speak for his ear alone. "Rand, there is a Waygate nearby. I can feel it."

"ju min ðɪs wɑz ən oʊɡiɝ ɡɹoʊv?" ɹænd sɛd sɔfli, ən lɔɪəl nɑɾəd.

"You mean this was an Ogier grove?" Rand said softly, and Loial nodded.

"stɛɾɪŋ tsəfu hæd nɑt bɪn faʊn əɡɛn wən ɪt wɑz plæntəd, əɹ ði oʊɡiɝ u hɛlp bɪld ɑlkɛɹəhinælən wəd nɑɾ əv niɾəd ə ɡɹoʊv tə ɹimaɪn əm ə ðə stɛɾɪŋ. ðɪs wɑz ɔl fɔɹəst wən aɪ keɪm θɹu kɛɹhin bɪfɔɹ, ən bɪlɔŋ tə ðə kɪŋ."

"Stedding Tsofu had not been found again when it was planted, or the Ogier who helped build Al'cair'rahienallen would not have needed a grove to remind them of the stedding. This was all forest when I came through Cairhien before, and belonged to the King."

"bɑɹθeɪnz pɹɑbli tʊk ɪɾ əweɪ ɪn səm plɑt." ɹænd lʊkt ɝaʊn ðə ɹum nɝvəsli. ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz stɪl tɔkɪŋ, bʌt mɔɹ ðən ə fju wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ ði oʊɡiɝ ən hɪm. hi kəd nɑt si ɪŋtʃɹ. vɛɹɪn stʊɾ ət ðə sɛntɝ ʌv ə nɑɾ ʌv wɪmən. "aɪ wɪʃ wi kəd steɪ təɡɛðɝ."

"Barthanes probably took it away in some plot." Rand looked around the room nervously. Everyone was still talking, but more than a few were watching the Ogier and him. He could not see Ingtar. Verin stood at the center of a knot of women. "I wish we could stay together."

"vɛɹɪn sɛz nɑt, ɹænd. ʃi sɛz ɪt wəd meɪk əm ɔl səspɪʃəs ən æŋɡɹi, θɪŋkɪŋ wi wɝ hoʊldɪŋ aʊɝsɛlvz əluf. wɪv tə əleɪ səspɪʃən əntɪl mæt ən hʊɹɪn faɪnd wʌtɛvɝ ðeɪ faɪnd."

"Verin says not, Rand. She says it would make them all suspicious and angry, thinking we were holding ourselves aloof. We have to allay suspicion until Mat and Hurin find whatever they find."

"aɪ hɝd wʌt ʃi sɛɾ əz wɛl əz ju, lɔɪəl. bʌɾ aɪ stɪl seɪ, ɪf bɑɹθeɪnz ɪz ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd, ðən i mʌs noʊ waɪ wɝ hɪɹ. ɡoʊɪŋ ɔf baɪ aʊɝsɛlvz ɪz dʒʌst æskɪŋ tə bi nɑkt ɑn ðə hɛd."

"I heard what she said as well as you, Loial. But I still say, if Barthanes is a Darkfriend, then he must know why we're here. Going off by ourselves is just asking to be knocked on the head."

"vɛɹɪn sɛz i woʊn də ɛniθɪŋ əntɪl i faɪnz aʊt wɛðɝ i kən meɪk jus ʌv ʌs. dʒʌs də wʌt ʃi toʊld ʌs, ɹænd. ɛɛs sədaɪ noʊ wʌt ðeɪ ɑɹ əbaʊt." lɔɪəl wɔkt ɪndə ðə kɹaʊd, ɡæðɝɪŋ ə sɝkəl ə lɔɹdz ən leɪɾiz bɪfɔɹ i hæd ɡɔn tɛn stɛps.

"Verin says he won't do anything until he finds out whether he can make use of us. Just do what she told us, Rand. Aes Sedai know what they are about." Loial walked into the crowd, gathering a circle of lords and ladies before he had gone ten steps.

ʌðɝz stɑɹɾəd təwɔɹd ɹænd, naʊ ðəɾ i wɑz əloʊn, bʌɾ i tɝn ɪn ði ʌðɝ dɝɛkʃən ən hɝiɾ əweɪ. ɛɛs sədaɪ meɪ noʊ wʌt ðəɹ əbaʊt, bʌɾ aɪ wɪʃ aɪ dɪd. aɪ doʊn laɪk ðɪs. laɪt, bʌɾ aɪ wɪʃ aɪ nu ɪf ʃi wɑz tɛlɪŋ ðə tʃɹuθ. ɛɛs sədaɪ nɛvɝ laɪ, bʌt ðə tʃɹuθ jə hɪɹ meɪ nɑt bi ðə tʃɹuθ jə θɪŋk ɪɾ ɪz.

Others started toward Rand, now that he was alone, but he turned in the other direction and hurried away. Aes Sedai may know what they're about, but I wish I did. I don't like this. Light, but I wish I knew if she was telling the truth. Aes Sedai never lie, but the truth you hear may not be the truth you think it is.

hi kɛp muvɪŋ tə əvɔɪd tɔkɪŋ wɪð ðə noʊbəlz. ðəɹ wɝ mɛni ʌðɝ ɹumz, ɔl fɪld wɪð lɔɹdz ən leɪɾiz, ɔl wɪð ɛntɝteɪnɝz: θɹi dɪfɹənt ɡlimən ɪn ðɛɹ kloʊks, mɔɹ dʒʌɡəlɝz ən tʌmblɝz, ən mjuzɪʃənz pleɪɪŋ fluts, bɪɾɝnz, dʌlsɪmɝz, ən luts, plʌs faɪv dɪfɹən saɪzəz ə fɪɾəl, sɪks kaɪnz ə hɔɹn, stʃɹeɪɾ əɹ kɝvd əɹ kɝld, ən tɛn saɪzəz ə dʒɹʌm fɹəm tæmbɝ tə kɛɾəl. hi ɡeɪv səm ə ðə hɔɹn pleɪɝz ə sɛkən lʊk, ðoʊz wɪð kɝl hɔɹnz, bʌt ði ɪnstʃɹəməns wɝ ɔl pleɪn bɹæs.

He kept moving to avoid talking with the nobles. There were many other rooms, all filled with lords and ladies, all with entertainers: three different gleemen in their cloaks, more jugglers and tumblers, and musicians playing flutes, bitterns, dulcimers, and lutes, plus five different sizes of fiddle, six kinds of horn, straight or curved or curled, and ten sizes of drum from tambour to kettle. He gave some of the horn players a second look, those with curled horns, but the instruments were all plain brass.

ðeɪ wʊdn əv ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ aʊt hɪɹ, ful, hi θɔt. nɑɾ ənlɛs bɑɹθeɪnz minz tə hæv dɛd hɪɹoʊz kʌm əz pɑɹɾ ə ði ɛntɝteɪnmənt.

They wouldn't have the Horn of Valere out here, fool, he thought. Not unless Barthanes means to have dead heroes come as part of the entertainment.

ðəɹ wɑz ivən ə bɑɹɾ ɪn sɪlvɝ-wɝk tɛɹən buts ən ə jɛloʊ koʊt, stʃɹoʊlɪŋ θɹu ðə ɹumz plʌkɪŋ ɪz hɑɹp ən səmtaɪmz stɑpɪŋ tə dɪkleɪm ɪn haɪ tʃænt. hi ɡlɛɹd kəntɛmptʃwəsli ət ðə ɡlimən ən dɪd nɑt lɪŋɡɝ ɪn ðə ɹumz wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ, bʌt ɹænd sɔ lɪɾəl dɪfɝəns bɪtwin ɪm ən əm ɪksɛp fəɹ ðɛɹ kloʊðz.

There was even a bard in silver-worked Tairen boots and a yellow coat, strolling through the rooms plucking his harp and sometimes stopping to declaim in High Chant. He glared contemptuously at the gleemen and did not linger in the rooms where they were, but Rand saw little difference between him and them except for their clothes.

sʌɾənli bɑɹθeɪnz wɑz wɔkɪŋ baɪ ɹændz saɪd. ə lɪvɹid sɝvən ɪmiɾiətli ɔfɝɾ ɪz sɪlvɝ tʃɹeɪ wɪð ə baʊ. bɑɹθeɪnz tʊk ə bloʊn-ɡlæs ɡɑbləɾ ʌv waɪn. wɔkɪŋ bækwɝdz əhɛɾ ə ðɛm stɪl boʊɪŋ, ðə sɝvən hɛl ðə tʃɹeɪ təwɔɹd ɹænd əntɪl ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, ðən mɛltəɾ ɪndə ðə kɹaʊd.

Suddenly Barthanes was walking by Rand's side. A liveried servant immediately offered his silver tray with a bow. Barthanes took a blown-glass goblet of wine. Walking backwards ahead of them still bowing, the servant held the tray toward Rand until Rand shook his head, then melted into the crowd.

"ju sim ɹɛsləs," bɑɹθeɪnz sɛd, sɪpɪŋ.

"You seem restless," Barthanes said, sipping.

"aɪ laɪk tə wɔk." ɹænd wʌndɝd haʊ tə fɑloʊ vɛɹɪnz ædvaɪs, ən ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ wʌt ʃi hæd sɛɾ əbaʊɾ ɪz vɪzət tə ði æmɪɝlɪn, hi sɛɾəld ɪndə kæt kɹɔsɪz ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd. hi nu noʊ mɔɹ ɛɹəɡənt weɪ tə wɔk ðən ðæt. bɑɹθeɪnzəz maʊθ taɪɾənd, ən ɹænd θɔt pɝhæps ðə lɔɹd faʊn ɪt tu ɛɹəɡənt, bʌt vɛɹɪnz ædvaɪs wɑz ɔl i hæd tə ɡoʊ baɪ, soʊ hi dɪd nɑt stɑp. tə teɪk səm ə ði ɛdʒ ɔf, hi sɛd plɛzənli, "ðɪs ɪz ə faɪn pɑɹɾi. juv mɛni fɹɛnz, ən aɪv nɛvɝ sin soʊ mɛni ɛntɝteɪnɝz."

"I like to walk." Rand wondered how to follow Verin's advice, and remembering what she had said about his visit to the Amyrlin, he settled into Cat Crosses the Courtyard. He knew no more arrogant way to walk than that. Barthanes's mouth tightened, and Rand thought perhaps the lord found it too arrogant, but Verin's advice was all he had to go by, so he did not stop. To take some of the edge off, he said pleasantly, "This is a fine party. You have many friends, and I've never seen so many entertainers."

"mɛni fɹɛnz," bɑɹθeɪnz əɡɹid. "ju kən tɛl ɡɔlʒɹiən haʊ mɛni, ən hu. səm ə ðə neɪmz maɪt sɝpɹaɪz hɪm."

"Many friends," Barthanes agreed. "You can tell Galldrian how many, and who. Some of the names might surprise him."

"aɪ hæv nɛvɝ mɛt ðə kɪŋ, lɔɹd bɑɹθeɪnz, ən aɪ doʊn ɪkspɛkt aɪ ɛvɝ wɪl."

"I have never met the King, Lord Barthanes, and I don't expect I ever will."

"ʌv kɔɹs. jə dʒʌs hæpən tə bi ɪn ðət flaɪspɛk vɪlədʒ. jə wɝ nɑt tʃɛkɪŋ ɑn ðə pɹɑɡɹɛs ə ɹitʃɹivɪŋ ðət stætʃu. ə ɡɹeɪɾ ʌndɝteɪkɪŋ, ðæt."

"Of course. You just happened to be in that flyspeck village. You were not checking on the progress of retrieving that statue. A great undertaking, that."

"jɛs." hi hæd bɪɡʌn θɪŋkɪŋ ə vɛɹɪn əɡɛn, wɪʃɪŋ ʃi hæd ɡɪvən ɪm səm ædvaɪs ɑn haʊ tə tɔk wɪð ə mæn u əsumd i wɑz laɪɪŋ. hi æɾəd wɪθaʊt θɪŋkɪŋ, "ɪts deɪnʒɝəs tə mɛɾəl wɪð θɪŋz fɹəm ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz ɪf jə doʊnt noʊ wʌt jə ɑɹ duɪŋ."

"Yes." He had begun thinking of Verin again, wishing she had given him some advice on how to talk with a man who assumed he was lying. He added without thinking, "It's dangerous to meddle with things from the Age of Legends if you don't know what you are doing."

bɑɹθeɪnz pɪɹɾ ɪndə hɪz waɪn, mjuzɪŋ əz ɪf ɹænd hæd dʒʌst sɛd sʌmθɪŋ pɹoʊfaʊnd. "ɑɹ jə seɪɪŋ jə də nɑt səpɔɹt ɡɔlʒɹiən ɪn ðɪs?" hi æsk faɪnəli.

Barthanes peered into his wine, musing as if Rand had just said something profound. "Are you saying you do not support Galldrian in this?" he asked finally.

"aɪ toʊl ju, aɪv nɛvɝ mɛt ðə kɪŋ."

"I told you, I've never met the King."

"jɛs, ʌv kɔɹs. aɪ dɪd nɑt noʊ ændɝmən pleɪɾ ət ðə ɡɹeɪt ɡeɪm soʊ wɛl. wi də nɑt si mɛni hɪɹ ɪn kɛɹhin."

"Yes, of course. I did not know Andormen played at the Great Game so well. We do not see many here in Cairhien."

ɹænd tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ tə stɑp fɹəm tɛlɪŋ ðə mæn æŋɡɹəli ðəɾ i wɑz nɑt pleɪɪŋ ðɛɹ ɡeɪm. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ mɛni ɡɹeɪn bɑɹdʒəz fɹəm ændɝ ɪn ðə ɹɪvɝ."

Rand took a deep breath to stop from telling the man angrily that he was not playing their Game. "There are many grain barges from Andor in the river."

"mɝtʃəns ən tʃɹeɪɾɝz. hu noʊɾəsəz sətʃ əz ðeɪ? əz wɛl noʊɾəs ðə biɾəlz ɑn ðə livz." bɑɹθeɪnzəz vɔɪs kæɹiɾ ikwəl kəntɛmp fəɹ boʊθ biɾəlz ən mɝtʃəns, bʌt wʌns əɡɛn i fɹaʊn əz ɪf ɹænd hæd hɪntəɾ ət sʌmθɪŋ. "nɑt mɛni mɛn tʃɹævəl ɪn kʌmpəni wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ. jə sim tu jʌŋ tə bi ə wɔɹɾɝ. aɪ səpoʊz lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹ ɪz vɛɹɪn sədaɪz wɔɹɾɝ?"

"Merchants and traders. Who notices such as they? As well notice the beetles on the leaves." Barthanes's voice carried equal contempt for both beetles and merchants, but once again he frowned as if Rand had hinted at something. "Not many men travel in company with Aes Sedai. You seem too young to be a Warder. I suppose Lord Ingtar is Verin Sedai's Warder?"

"wi ɑɹ u wi sɛd wi ɑɹ," ɹænd sɛd, ən ɡɹɪməst. ɪksɛp mi.

"We are who we said we are," Rand said, and grimaced. Except me.

bɑɹθeɪnz wɑz stʌɾiɪŋ ɹændz feɪs ɔlmoʊst oʊpənli. "jʌŋ. jʌŋ tə kæɹi ə hɛɹən-mɑɹk bleɪd."

Barthanes was studying Rand's face almost openly. "Young. Young to carry a heron-mark blade."

"aɪ æm lɛs ðən ə jɪɹ oʊld," ɹænd sɛɾ ɔɾəmætɪkli, ən ɪmiɾiətli wɪʃt i hæɾ ɪt bæk. ɪt saʊndəd fulɪʃ, tə hɪz ɪɹ, bʌt vɛɹɪn hæd sɛɾ ækt əz i hæd wɪð ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, ən ðət wɑz ði ænsɝ læn hæd ɡɪvən hɪm. eɪ bɔɹɾɝmən kənsɪɾɝd ðə deɪ hi wɑz ɡɪvən ɪz sɔɹd tə bi hɪz neɪmdeɪ.

"I am less than a year old," Rand said automatically, and immediately wished he had it back. It sounded foolish, to his ear, but Verin had said act as he had with the Amyrlin Seat, and that was the answer Lan had given him. A Borderman considered the day he was given his sword to be his nameday.

"soʊ. ən ændɔɝmən, ən jɛt bɔɹɾɝlənd-tʃɹeɪnd. əɹ ɪz ɪt wɔɹɾɝ-tʃɹeɪnd?" bɑɹθeɪnzəz aɪz nɛɹoʊd, stʌɾiɪŋ ɹænd. "aɪ ʌndɝstæn mɔɹɡeɪs əz oʊnli wʌn sʌn. neɪmd ɡɔɪn, aɪ hæv hɝd. jə mʌs bi mʌtʃ laɪk ɪm ɪn eɪdʒ."

"So. An Andorman, and yet Borderland-trained. Or is it Warder-trained?" Barthanes's eyes narrowed, studying Rand. "I understand Morgase has only one son. Named Gawyn, I have heard. You must be much like him in age."

"aɪ hæv mɛt hɪm," ɹænd sɛd kɔʃəsli.

"I have met him," Rand said cautiously.

"ðoʊz aɪz. ðət hɛɹ. aɪ hæv hɝd ði ændɔɝən ɹɔɪəl laɪn əz ɔlmoʊst il kʌlɝɪŋ ɪn ðɛɹ hɛɹ ən aɪz."

"Those eyes. That hair. I have heard the Andoran royal line has almost Aiel coloring in their hair and eyes."

ɹænd stʌmbəld, ðoʊ ðə flɔɹ wɑz smuð mɑɹbəl. "aɪm nɑɾ il, lɔɹd bɑɹθeɪnz, ən aɪm nɑɾ ə ðə ɹɔɪəl laɪn, iðɝ."

Rand stumbled, though the floor was smooth marble. "I'm not Aiel, Lord Barthanes, and I'm not of the royal line, either."

"æz jə seɪ. juv ɡɪvən mi mʌtʃ tə θɪŋk ɑn. aɪ bɪliv wi meɪ faɪn kɑmən ɡɹaʊnd wən wi tɔk əɡɛn." bɑɹθeɪnz nɑɾəd ən ɹeɪzd ɪz ɡlæs ɪn ə smɔl səlut, ðən tɝn tə spik tə ə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd mæn wɪð mɛni stʃɹaɪps ə kʌlɝ daʊn ɪz koʊt.

"As you say. You have given me much to think on. I believe we may find common ground when we talk again." Barthanes nodded and raised his glass in a small salute, then turned to speak to a gray-haired man with many stripes of color down his coat.

ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛɾ ən muvd ɑn, əweɪ fɹəm mɔɹ kɑnvɝseɪʃən. ɪt hæd bɪn bæɾ ɪnʌf tɔkɪŋ tə wʌn kɛɹhinɪn lɔɹd; hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə ɹɪsk tu. bɑɹθeɪnz əpɪɹd tə faɪn dip minɪŋz ɪn ðə moʊs tʃɹɪviəl kɑmɛns. ɹænd ɹilaɪzd i hæd dʒʌs naʊ lɝn ɪnʌf ə deɪz deɪmɑɹ tə noʊ hi hæd noʊ aɪdiə əɾ ɔl haʊ ɪt wɑz pleɪd. mæt, hʊɹɪn, faɪn sʌmθɪŋ fæst, soʊ wi kən ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə hɪɹ. ðiz pipəl ɑɹ kɹeɪzi.

Rand shook his head and moved on, away from more conversation. It had been bad enough talking to one Cairhienin lord; he did not want to risk two. Barthanes appeared to find deep meanings in the most trivial comments. Rand realized he had just now learned enough of Daes Dae'mar to know he had no idea at all how it was played. Mat, Hurin, find something fast, so we can get out of here. These people are crazy.

ən ðən i ɛntɝɾ ənʌðɝ ɹum, ən ðə ɡlimən ət ði ɛn ʌv ɪt, stʃɹʌmɪŋ ɪz hɑɹp ən ɹisaɪɾɪŋ ə teɪl fɹəm ðə ɡɹeɪt hʌn ə ðə hɔɹn, wɑz tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn. ɹænd stɑp dɛd. tɑm dɪd nɑt sim tə si hɪm, ðoʊ ðə ɡlimənz ɡeɪz pæst oʊvɝ ɪm twaɪs. ɪt sim ðət tɑm hæd mɛnt wʌɾ i sɛd. ə klin bɹeɪk.

And then he entered another room, and the gleeman at the end of it, strumming his harp and reciting a tale from The Great Hunt of the Horn, was Thom Merrilin. Rand stopped dead. Thom did not seem to see him, though the gleeman's gaze passed over him twice. It seemed that Thom had meant what he said. A clean break.

ɹænd tɝn tə ɡoʊ, bʌɾ ə wʊmən stɛp smuðli ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm ən pʊɾ ə hæn ɑn ɪz tʃɛst, ðə leɪs fɔlɪŋ bæk fɹəm ə sɑft ɹɪst. hɝ hɛd dɪd nɑt kwaɪt kʌm tə hɪz ʃoʊldɝ, bʌɾ əɹ tɔl ɝeɪ ʌv kɝlz izəli ɹitʃt əz haɪ əz ɪz aɪz. ðə haɪ nɛk ə hɝ ɡaʊn pʊt leɪs ɹʌfəlz ʌndɝ əɹ tʃɪn, ən stʃɹaɪps kʌvɝd ðə fɹʌn ə hɝ dɑɹk blu dʒɹɛs bɪloʊ hɝ bɹɛsts. "aɪ æm əleɪn tʃuliəndɝd, ən jə ɑɹ ðə feɪməs ɹænd ælθɹ. ɪn bɑɹθeɪnzəz oʊn mænɝ, aɪ səpoʊz hiz ðə ɹaɪt tə spik tə jə fɝst, bʌt wəɹ ɔl fæsəneɪɾəd baɪ wʌt wi hɪɹ ə ju. aɪ ivən hɪɹ ðət jə pleɪ ðə flut. kən ɪt bi tʃɹu?"

Rand turned to go, but a woman stepped smoothly in front of him and put a hand on his chest, the lace falling back from a soft wrist. Her head did not quite come to his shoulder, but her tall array of curls easily reached as high as his eyes. The high neck of her gown put lace ruffles under her chin, and stripes covered the front of her dark blue dress below her breasts. "I am Alaine Chuliandred, and you are the famous Rand al'Thor. In Barthanes's own manor, I suppose he has the right to speak to you first, but we are all fascinated by what we hear of you. I even hear that you play the flute. Can it be true?"

"aɪ pleɪ ðə flut." haʊ dɪd ʃi . . . ? kɔldɛvwɪn. laɪt, ɛvɹibɑɾi dʌz hɪɹ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪn kɛɹhin. "ɪf jəl ɪkskjuz - "

"I play the flute." How did she . . . ? Caldevwin. Light, everybody does hear everything in Cairhien. "If you will excuse - "

"aɪ hæv hɝd ðət səm aʊtlæn lɔɹdz pleɪ mjuzɪk, bʌɾ aɪ nɛvɝ bɪlivd ɪt. aɪ wəd laɪk vɛɹi mʌtʃ tə hɪɹ jə pleɪ. pɝhæps jəl tɔk wɪð mi, ʌv ðɪs ən ðæt. bɑɹθeɪnz sim tə faɪn jəɹ kɑnvɝseɪʃən fæsəneɪɾɪŋ. maɪ hʌzbən spɛnz ɪz deɪz sæmplɪŋ ɪz oʊn vɪnjɝdz, ən livz mi kwaɪɾ əloʊn. hiz nɛvɝ ðəɹ tə tɔk wɪð mi."

"I have heard that some outland lords play music, but I never believed it. I would like very much to hear you play. Perhaps you will talk with me, of this and that. Barthanes seemed to find your conversation fascinating. My husband spends his days sampling his own vineyards, and leaves me quite alone. He is never there to talk with me."

"ju mʌs mɪs hɪm," ɹænd sɛd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɛdʒ ɝaʊn əɹ ən əɹ waɪd skɝts. ʃi ɡeɪv ə tɪŋkəlɪŋ læf əz ɪf i hæd sɛd ðə fʌniəs θɪŋ ɪn ðə wɝld.

"You must miss him," Rand said, trying to edge around her and her wide skirts. She gave a tinkling laugh as if he had said the funniest thing in the world.

ənʌðɝ wʊmən saɪɾəld ɪn bɪsaɪd ðə fɝst, ən ənʌðɝ hænd wɑz leɪɾ ɑn ɪz tʃɛst. ʃi wɔɹ əz mɛni stʃɹaɪps əz əleɪn, ən ðeɪ wɝ ʌv ən eɪdʒ, ə ɡʊd tɛn jɪɹz oʊldɝ ðən hi. "du jə θɪŋk tə kip ɪm tə jɝsɛlf, əleɪn?" ðə tu wɪmən smaɪld əɾ itʃ ʌðɝ waɪl ðɛɹ aɪz θɹu dæɡɝz. ðə sɛkən tɝn əɹ smaɪl ɑn ɹænd. "aɪ æm bɪləveɪɪɹ əsiɛlɪn. ɑɹ ɔl ændɝmən soʊ tɔl? ən soʊ hænsəm?"

Another woman sidled in beside the first, and another hand was laid on his chest. She wore as many stripes as Alaine, and they were of an age, a good ten years older than he. "Do you think to keep him to yourself, Alaine?" The two women smiled at each other while their eyes threw daggers. The second turned her smile on Rand. "I am Belevaere Osiellin. Are all Andormen so tall? And so handsome?"

hi klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊt. "ɑ . . . səm ɑɹ əz tɔl. pɑɹɾən mi, bʌɾ ɪf jəl - "

He cleared his throat. "Ah . . . some are as tall. Pardon me, but if you will - "

"aɪ sɔ jə tɔkɪŋ wɪð bɑɹθeɪnz. ðeɪ seɪ jə noʊ ɡɔlʒɹiən, əz wɛl. jə mʌs kʌm tə si mi, ən tɔk. maɪ hʌzbən ɪz vɪzəɾɪŋ əɹ ɪsteɪts ɪn ðə saʊθ."

"I saw you talking with Barthanes. They say you know Galldrian, as well. You must come to see me, and talk. My husband is visiting our estates in the south."

"ju hæv ðə sʌblɪɾi ʌv ə tævɝn wɛnk," əleɪn hɪst ət hɝ, ən ɪmiɾiətli wɑz smaɪlɪŋ ʌp ət ɹænd. "ʃi hæz noʊ pɑlɪʃ. noʊ mæn kəd laɪk ə wʊmən wɪð ə mænɝ soʊ ɹʌf. bɹɪŋ jəɹ flut tə maɪ mænɝ, ən wɪl tɔk. pɝhæps jəl titʃ mi tə pleɪ?"

"You have the sublety of a tavern wench," Alaine hissed at her, and immediately was smiling up at Rand. "She has no polish. No man could like a woman with a manner so rough. Bring your flute to my manor, and we will talk. Perhaps you will teach me to play?"

"wʌɾ əleɪn θɪŋks ʌv əz sʌɾəlti," bɪləveɪɪɹ sɛd switli, "ɪz bʌt læk ə kɝədʒ. ə mæn u wɛɹz ə hɛɹən-mɑɹk sɔɹd mʌs bi bɹeɪv. ðət tʃɹuli ɪz ə hɛɹən-mɑɹk bleɪd, ɪz ɪt nɑt?"

"What Alaine thinks of as subtlety," Belevaere said sweetly, "is but lack of courage. A man who wears a heron-mark sword must be brave. That truly is a heron-mark blade, is it not?"

ɹænd tʃɹaɪd bækɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðɛm. "ɪf jəl dʒʌst ɪkskjuz mi, aɪ - " ðeɪ fɑloʊd stɛp fəɹ stɛp əntɪl ɪz bæk hɪt ðə wɔl; ðə wɪdθ ə ðɛɹ skɝts təɡɛðɝ meɪɾ ənʌðɝ wɔl ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm.

Rand tried backing away from them. "If you will just excuse me, I - " They followed step for step until his back hit the wall; the width of their skirts together made another wall in front of him.

hi dʒʌmpt əz ə θɝd wʊmən kɹaʊɾəd ɪn bɪsaɪd ði ʌðɝ tu, hɝ skɝts dʒɔɪnɪŋ ðɛɹz tə ðə wɔl ɑn ðət saɪd. ʃi wɑz oʊldɝ ðən ðeɪ, bʌt dʒʌst əz pɹɪɾi, wɪð ən əmjuz smaɪl ðət dɪd nɑt lɛsən ðə ʃɑɹpnəs ə hɝ aɪz. ʃi wɔɹ hæf əɡɛn əz mɛni stʃɹaɪps əz əleɪn ən bɪləveɪɪɹ; ðeɪ meɪd taɪni kɝtsiz ən ɡlɛɹɾ əɾ əɹ sʌlənli.

He jumped as a third woman crowded in beside the other two, her skirts joining theirs to the wall on that side. She was older than they, but just as pretty, with an amused smile that did not lessen the sharpness of her eyes. She wore half again as many stripes as Alaine and Belevaere; they made tiny curtsies and glared at her sullenly.

"ɑɹ ðiz tu spaɪɾɝz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə tɔɪl jə ɪn ðɛɹ wɛbz?" ði oʊldɝ wʊmən læft. "hæf ðə taɪm ðeɪ tæŋɡəl ðɛmsɛlvz mɔɹ fɝmli ðən ɛniwʌn ɛls. kʌm wɪð mi, maɪ faɪn jʌŋ ændɔɝən, ən əl tɛl jə səm ə ðə tʃɹʌbəlz ðeɪ wəd ɡɪv ju. fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ, aɪ hæv noʊ hʌzbən tə wɝi əbaʊt. hʌzbənz ɔlweɪz meɪk tʃɹʌbəl."

"Are these two spiders trying to toil you in their webs?" The older woman laughed. "Half the time they tangle themselves more firmly than anyone else. Come with me, my fine young Andoran, and I will tell you some of the troubles they would give you. For one thing, I have no husband to worry about. Husbands always make trouble."

oʊvɝ əleɪnz hɛɾ i kəd si tɑm, stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ fɹəm ə baʊ tə noʊ əplɔz əɹ noʊɾəs wʌtsoʊɛvɝ. wɪð ə ɡɹɪmɑs ðə ɡlimən snætʃt ə ɡɑblət fɹəm ðə tʃɹeɪ ʌv ə stɑɹɾəld sɝvənt.

Over Alaine's head he could see Thom, straightening from a bow to no applause or notice whatsoever. With a grimace the gleeman snatched a goblet from the tray of a startled servant.

"aɪ si sʌmwʌn aɪ mʌst spik tə," ɹænd toʊl ðə wɪmən, ən skwizd aʊɾ ə ðə bɑks ðeɪ hæd pʊɾ ɪm ɪn dʒʌst əz ðə læst wʊmən ɹitʃt fəɹ ɪz ɑɹm. ɔl θɹi stɛɹɾ æftɝ ɪm əz i hɝid tə ðə ɡlimən.

"I see someone I must speak to," Rand told the women, and squeezed out of the box they had put him in just as the last woman reached for his arm. All three stared after him as he hurried to the gleeman.

tɑm aɪɾ ɪm oʊvɝ ðə lɪp ə ðə ɡɑblət, ðən tʊk ənʌðɝ lɔŋ swɑloʊ.

Thom eyed him over the lip of the goblet, then took another long swallow.

"tɑm, aɪ noʊ jə sɛɾ ə klin bɹeɪk, bʌɾ aɪ hæd tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ fɹəm ðoʊz wɪmən. ɔl ðeɪ wɑntəd tə tɔk əbaʊt wɑz ðɛɹ hʌzbənz biɪŋ əweɪ, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi hɪntɪŋ əɾ ʌðɝ θɪŋz." tɑm tʃoʊkt ɑn ɪz waɪn, ən ɹænd slæpt ɪz bæk. "ju dʒɹɪŋk tu fæst, ən sʌmθɪŋ ɔlweɪz ɡoʊz daʊn ðə ɹɔŋ weɪ. tɑm, ðeɪ θɪŋk aɪm plɑɾɪŋ wɪð bɑɹθeɪnz, əɹ meɪbi ɡɔlʒɹiən, ən aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðəl bɪliv mi wən aɪ seɪ aɪm nɑt. aɪ dʒʌs niɾəd ən ɪkskjus tə liv ðɛm."

"Thom, I know you said a clean break, but I had to get away from those women. All they wanted to talk about was their husbands being away, but they were already hinting at other things." Thom choked on his wine, and Rand slapped his back. "You drink too fast, and something always goes down the wrong way. Thom, they think I am plotting with Barthanes, or maybe Galldrian, and I don't think they will believe me when I say I'm not. I just needed an excuse to leave them."

tɑm stʃɹoʊkt ɪz lɔŋ mʌstæʃɪz wɪð wʌn nʌkəl ən pɪɹɾ əkɹɔs ðə ɹum ət ðə θɹi wɪmən. ðeɪ wɝ stɪl stændɪŋ təɡɛðɝ, wɑtʃɪŋ ɹænd ən hɪm. "aɪ ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðoʊz θɹi, bɔɪ. bɹin tæbɔɹwɪn əloʊn wəd ɡɪv jə ən ɛdʒəkeɪʃən sətʃ əz ɛvɹi mæn ʃəɾ əv ət list wʌns ɪn ɪz laɪf, ɪf i kən lɪv θɹu ɪt. wɝiɾ əbaʊt ðɛɹ hʌzbənz. aɪ laɪk ðæt, bɔɪ." əbɹʌpli hɪz aɪz ʃɑɹpənd. "ju toʊl mi jə wɝ klɪɹ ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ. hæf ðə tɔk hɪɹ tənaɪɾ ɪz ə ði ændɔɝən lɔɹɾ əpɪɹɪŋ wɪð noʊ wɔɹnɪŋ, ən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ əɾ ɪz saɪd. bɑɹθeɪnz ən ɡɔlʒɹiən. juv lɛt ðə waɪt taʊɝ pʊt jə ɪn ðə kʊkɪŋ pɑt ðɪs taɪm."

Thom stroked his long mustaches with one knuckle and peered across the room at the three women. They were still standing together, watching Rand and him. "I recognize those three, boy. Breane Taborwin alone would give you an education such as every man should have at least once in his life, if he can live through it. Worried about their husbands. I like that, boy." Abruptly his eyes sharpened. "You told me you were clear of Aes Sedai. Half the talk here tonight is of the Andoran lord appearing with no warning, and an Aes Sedai at his side. Barthanes and Galldrian. You've let the White Tower put you in the cooking pot this time."

"ʃi oʊnli keɪm jɛstɝdeɪ, tɑm. ən əz sun əz ðə hɔɹn ɪz seɪf, əl bi fɹi ʌv əm əɡɛn. aɪ min tə si tə ɪt."

"She only came yesterday, Thom. And as soon as the Horn is safe, I'll be free of them again. I mean to see to it."

"ju saʊn əz ɪf ɪɾ ɪzən seɪf naʊ," tɑm sɛd sloʊli. "ju dɪdn saʊn ðət weɪ bɪfɔɹ."

"You sound as if it isn't safe now," Thom said slowly. "You didn't sound that way before."

"dɑɹkfɹɛnz stoʊl ɪt, tɑm. ðeɪ bɹɔɾ ɪt hɪɹ. bɑɹθeɪnz ɪz wʌn ə ðɛm."

"Darkfriends stole it, Thom. They brought it here. Barthanes is one of them."
