tɑm sim tə stʌɾi hɪz waɪn, bʌɾ ɪz aɪz dɑɹɾɪd tə meɪk ʃʊɹ noʊ wʌn wɑz kloʊs ɪnʌf tə lɪsən. mɔɹ ðən ðə θɹi wɪmən wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ əm wɪð saɪdweɪz ɡlænsɪz waɪl pɹitɛndɪŋ tə tɔk əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz, bʌɾ ɛvɹi nɑt meɪnteɪn ɪts dɪstəns fɹəm ɛvɹi ʌðɝ. stɪl, tɑm spoʊk sɔfli. "ə deɪnʒɝəs θɪŋ tə seɪ ɪf ɪɾ ɪzən tʃɹu, ən mɔɹ deɪnʒɝəs ɪf ɪɾ ɪz. ən ækjəzeɪʃən laɪk ðæt, əɡɛns ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl mæn ɪn ðə kɪŋdəm. . . . jə seɪ hiz ðə hɔɹn? aɪ səpoʊz jəɹ æftɝ maɪ hɛlp əɡɛn, naʊ ðət jəɹ tæŋɡəld wɪð ðə waɪt taʊɝ wʌns mɔɹ."

Thom seemed to study his wine, but his eyes darted to make sure no one was close enough to listen. More than the three women were watching them with sideways glances while pretending to talk among themselves, but every knot maintained its distance from every other. Still, Thom spoke softly. "A dangerous thing to say if it isn't true, and more dangerous if it is. An accusation like that, against the most powerful man in the kingdom. . . . You say he has the Horn? I suppose you're after my help again, now that you're tangled with the White Tower once more."

"noʊ." hi hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd tɑm hæd bɪn ɹaɪt, ivən ɪf ðə ɡlimən dɪd nɑt noʊ waɪ. hi kəd nɑɾ ɪnvɑlv ɛniwʌn ɛls ɪn ɪz tʃɹʌbəlz. "aɪ dʒʌst wɑntəd tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ fɹəm ðoʊz wɪmən."

"No." He had decided Thom had been right, even if the gleeman did not know why. He could not involve anyone else in his troubles. "I just wanted to get away from those women."

ðə ɡlimən blu aʊɾ ɪz mʌstæʃɪz, teɪkən əbæk. "wɛl. jɛs. ðəɾ ɪz wɛl. ðə læs taɪm aɪ hɛlp ju, aɪ ɡɑɾ ə lɪmp aʊɾ ʌv ɪt, ən jə sim tə hæv lɛt jɝsɛlf bi taɪd tə tɑɹ vəlɑn stʃɹɪŋz əɡɛn. jəl əv tə ɡɛt jɝsɛlf aʊɾ ʌv ɪt ðɪs taɪm." hi saʊndəɾ əz ɪf i wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kənvɪns hɪmsɛlf.

The gleeman blew out his mustaches, taken aback. "Well. Yes. That is well. The last time I helped you, I got a limp out of it, and you seem to have let yourself be tied to Tar Valon strings again. You'll have to get yourself out of it this time." He sounded as if he were trying to convince himself.

"aɪ wɪl, tɑm. aɪ wɪl." dʒʌst əz sun əz ðə hɔɹn ɪz seɪf ən mæt əz ðət blʌɾi dæɡɝ bæk. mæt, hʊɹɪn, wɛɹ ɑɹ ju?

"I will, Thom. I will." Just as soon as the Horn is safe and Mat has that bloody dagger back. Mat, Hurin, where are you?

əz ɪf ðə θɔt hæd bɪn ə sʌmənz, hʊɹɪn əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə ɹum, aɪz sɝtʃɪŋ əmʌŋ ðə lɔɹdz ən leɪɾiz. ðeɪ lʊk θɹu hɪm; sɝvəns dɪd nɑɾ ɪɡzɪst ənlɛs niɾəd. wən i faʊn ɹænd ən tɑm, hi meɪɾ ɪz weɪ bɪtwin ðə smɔl klʌstɝz ə noʊbəlz ən baʊd tə ɹænd. "maɪ lɔɹd, aɪ wɑz sɛn tə tɛl ju. jəɹ mænsɝvən hæɾ ə fɔl ən twɪstəɾ ɪz ni. aɪ doʊnt noʊ haʊ bæd, maɪ lɔɹd."

As if the thought had been a summons, Hurin appeared in the room, eyes searching among the lords and ladies. They looked through him; servants did not exist unless needed. When he found Rand and Thom, he made his way between the small clusters of nobles and bowed to Rand. "My Lord, I was sent to tell you. Your manservant had a fall and twisted his knee. I don't know how bad, my Lord."

fəɹ ə moʊmən ɹænd stɛɹd bɪfɔɹ i ʌndɝstʊd. kɑnʃəs ʌv ɔl ði aɪz ɑn hɪm, hi spoʊk laʊdli ɪnʌf fəɹ ðə noʊbəlz kloʊsəs tə oʊvɝhɪɹ. "klʌmzi ful. wʌt ɡʊɾ ɪz i tə mi ɪf i kænt wɔk? aɪ səpoʊz aɪd bɛɾɝ kʌm si haʊ bædli hiz hɝt hɪmsɛlf."

For a moment Rand stared before he understood. Conscious of all the eyes on him, he spoke loudly enough for the nobles closest to overhear. "Clumsy fool. What good is he to me if he can't walk? I suppose I'd better come see how badly he's hurt himself."

ɪt sim tə bi ðə ɹaɪt θɪŋ tə seɪ. hʊɹɪn saʊndəd ɹɪlivd wən i baʊɾ əɡɛn ən sɛd, "æz maɪ lɔɹd wɪʃɪz. ɪf maɪ lɔɹd wɪl fɑloʊ mi?"

It seemed to be the right thing to say. Hurin sounded relieved when he bowed again and said, "As my Lord wishes. If my Lord will follow me?"

"ju pleɪ vɛɹi wɛl ət biɪŋ ə lɔɹd," tɑm sɛd sɔfli. "bʌt ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðɪs. kɛɹhinɪn meɪ pleɪ deɪz deɪmɑɹ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðə waɪt taʊɝ meɪd ðə ɡɹeɪt ɡeɪm ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs. wɑtʃ jɝsɛlf, bɔɪ." wɪð ə ɡlɛɹ ət ðə noʊbəlz, hi sɛɾ ɪz ɛmpti ɡɑbləɾ ɑn ðə tʃɹeɪ ʌv ə pæsɪŋ sɝvən ən stʃɹoʊld əweɪ, plʌkɪŋ ɪz hɑɹp. hi bɪɡæn ɹisaɪɾɪŋ ɡʊdwaɪf mili ən ðə sɪlk mɝtʃənt.

"You play very well at being a lord," Thom said softly. "But remember this. Cairhienin may play Daes Dae'mar, but it was the White Tower made the Great Game in the first place. Watch yourself, boy." With a glare at the nobles, he set his empty goblet on the tray of a passing servant and strolled away, plucking his harp. He began reciting Goodwife Mili and the Silk Merchant.

"lɛɾ ɑn, mæn," ɹænd toʊl hʊɹɪn, filɪŋ fulɪʃ. əz i fɑloʊd ðə snɪfɝ aʊɾ ə ðə ɹum, hi kəd fil ði aɪz fɑloʊɪŋ hɪm.

"Lead on, man," Rand told Hurin, feeling foolish. As he followed the sniffer out of the room, he could feel the eyes following him.


tʃæptɝ θɝɾiθɹi

eɪ mɛsədʒ fɹəm ðə dɑɹk


A Message from the Dark

"hæv jə faʊn ɪt?" ɹænd æskt əz i fɑloʊd hʊɹɪn daʊn ə kɹæmp flaɪɾ ə stɛɹz. ðə kɪtʃənz leɪ ɑn ðə loʊɝ lɛvəlz, ən ðə sɝvəns u hæd kʌm ətɛndɪŋ ðə ɡɛsts hæɾ ɔl bɪn sɛn ðɛɹ. "ɔɹ ɪz mæt ɹɪli hɝt?"

"Have you found it?" Rand asked as he followed Hurin down a cramped flight of stairs. The kitchens lay on the lower levels, and the servants who had come attending the guests had all been sent there. "Or is Mat really hurt?"

"oʊ, mæts faɪn, lɔɹd ɹænd." ðə snɪfɝ fɹaʊnd. "æt list, hi saʊnz ɔl ɹaɪt, ən i ɡɹʌmbəlz laɪk ə heɪl mæn. aɪ dɪdn min tə wɝi ju, bʌɾ aɪ niɾəd ə ɹizən fəɹ jə tə kʌm bɪloʊ. aɪ faʊn ðə tʃɹeɪl izi ɪnʌf. ðə mɛn u sɛt faɪɝ tə ði ɪn ɔl ɛntɝɾ ə wɔld ɡɑɹɾən bɪhaɪn ðə mænɝ. tʃɹɑləks dʒɔɪn ðɛm, wɛn ɪndə ðə ɡɑɹɾən wɪð ðɛm. sʌmtaɪm jɛstɝdeɪ, aɪ θɪŋk. meɪbi ivən naɪt bɪfɔɹ læst." hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "lɔɹd ɹænd, ðeɪ dɪdn kʌm aʊɾ əɡɛn. ðeɪ mʌst stɪl bi ɪn ðɛɹ."

"Oh, Mat's fine, Lord Rand." The sniffer frowned. "At least, he sounds all right, and he grumbles like a hale man. I didn't mean to worry you, but I needed a reason for you to come below. I found the trail easy enough. The men who set fire to the inn all entered a walled garden behind the manor. Trollocs joined them, went into the garden with them. Sometime yesterday, I think. Maybe even night before last." He hesitated. "Lord Rand, they didn't come out again. They must still be in there."

ət ðə fʊɾ ə ðə stɛɹz ðə saʊnz ə ðə sɝvəns ɛndʒɔɪɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz dʒɹɪftəd daʊn ðə hɔl, læftɝ ən sɪŋɪŋ. sʌmwʌn hæɾ ə bɪɾɝn, stʃɹʌmɪŋ ə ɹɔkəs tun tə klæpɪŋ ən ðə θʌmp ə dænsɪŋ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ wɝk plæstɝ əɹ faɪn tæpəstʃɹiz hɪɹ, oʊnli bɛɹ stoʊn ən pleɪn wʊd. laɪɾ ɪn ðə hɔlz keɪm fɹəm ɹʌʃ tɔɹtʃɪz, smoʊkɪŋ ðə silɪŋ ən spɹɛd fɑɹ ɪnʌf əpɑɹt ðət ðə laɪt feɪɾəd bɪtwin ðɛm.

At the foot of the stairs the sounds of the servants enjoying themselves drifted down the hall, laughter and singing. Someone had a bittern, strumming a raucous tune to clapping and the thump of dancing. There was no worked plaster or fine tapestries here, only bare stone and plain wood. Light in the halls came from rush torches, smoking the ceiling and spread far enough apart that the light faded between them.

"aɪm ɡlæd jə ɑɹ tɔkɪŋ tə mi nætʃɹəli əɡɛn," ɹænd sɛd. "ðə weɪ juv bɪn boʊɪŋ ən skɹeɪpɪŋ, aɪ wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə θɪŋk jə wɝ mɔɹ kɛɹhinɪn ðən ðə kɛɹhinɪn."

"I'm glad you are talking to me naturally again," Rand said. "The way you have been bowing and scraping, I was beginning to think you were more Cairhienin than the Cairhienin."

hʊɹɪnz feɪs kʌlɝd. "wɛl, əz tə ðæt. . . ." hi ɡlæns daʊn ðə hɔl təwɔɹd ðə nɔɪz ən lʊkt əz ɪf i wɑntəd tə spɪt. "ðeɪ ɔl pɹitɛn tə bi soʊ pɹɑpɝ, bʌt. . . . lɔɹd ɹænd, ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðɛm sɛz hiz lɔɪəl tə hɪz mæstɝ əɹ mɪstʃɹəs, bʌt ðeɪ ɔl hɪn ðəɹ wɪlɪŋ tə sɛl wʌt ðeɪ noʊ, əɹ əv hɝd. ən wən ðeɪv ə fju dʒɹɪŋks ɪn ðɛm, ðəl tɛl ju, ɔl wɪspɝɪŋ ɪn jəɹ ɪɹ, θɪŋz əbaʊt ðə lɔɹdz ən leɪɾiz ðeɪ sɝv ðæɾəd fɛɹ meɪk jəɹ hɛɹ stæn ɑn ɛnd. aɪ noʊ ðəɹ kɛɹhinɪn, bʌɾ aɪ nɛvɝ hɝɾ ə sətʃ ɡoʊɪŋz ɑn."

Hurin's face colored. "Well, as to that. . . ." He glanced down the hall toward the noise and looked as if he wanted to spit. "They all pretend to be so proper, but. . . . Lord Rand, every one of them says he's loyal to his master or mistress, but they all hint they're willing to sell what they know, or have heard. And when they have a few drinks in them, they'll tell you, all whispering in your ear, things about the lords and ladies they serve that'd fair make your hair stand on end. I know they're Cairhienin, but I never heard of such goings on."

"wi wɪl bi aʊɾ ə hɪɹ sun, hʊɹɪn." ɹænd hoʊpt ɪt wɑz tʃɹu. "wɛɹ ɪz ðɪs ɡɑɹɾən?" hʊɹɪn tɝn daʊn ə saɪd hɔl liɾɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə bæk ə ðə mænɝ. "dɪd jə bɹɪŋ ɪŋtʃɹ ən ði ʌðɝz daʊn ɔlɹɛɾi?"

"We will be out of here soon, Hurin." Rand hoped it was true. "Where is this garden?" Hurin turned down a side hall leading toward the back of the manor. "Did you bring Ingtar and the others down already?"

ðə snɪfɝ ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹ hæd lɛt hɪmsɛlf bi kɔɹnɝd baɪ sɪks əɹ sɛvən ə ðoʊz u kɔl ðɛmsɛlvz leɪɾiz. aɪ kʊdnt ɡɛt kloʊs ɪnʌf tə spik tə hɪm. ən vɛɹɪn sədaɪ wɑz wɪð bɑɹθeɪnz. ʃi ɡeɪv mi sətʃ ə lʊk wən aɪ keɪm nɪɹ, aɪ nɛvɝ ivən tʃɹaɪd tə tɛl hɝ."

The sniffer shook his head. "Lord Ingtar had let himself be cornered by six or seven of those who call themselves ladies. I couldn't get close enough to speak to him. And Verin Sedai was with Barthanes. She gave me such a look when I came near, I never even tried to tell her."

ðeɪ ɹaʊndəɾ ənʌðɝ kɔɹnɝ dʒʌs ðɛn, ən ðəɹ wɝ lɔɪəl ən mæt, ði oʊɡiɝ stændɪŋ ə lɪɾəl stup fəɹ ðə loʊɝ silɪŋ.

They rounded another corner just then, and there were Loial and Mat, the Ogier standing a little stooped for the lower ceiling.

lɔɪəlz ɡɹɪn ɔlmoʊst splɪɾ ɪz feɪs. "ðɛɹ jə ɑɹ. ɹænd, aɪ wɑz nɛvɝ soʊ ɡlæd tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ fɹəm ɛniwʌn əz fɹəm ðoʊz pipəl əpstɛɹz. ðeɪ kɛpt æskɪŋ mi ɪf ði oʊɡiɝ wɝ kʌmɪŋ bæk, ən ɪf ɡɔlʒɹiən hæɾ əɡɹid tə peɪ wʌt wɑz oʊd. ɪt simz ðə ɹizən ɔl ði oʊɡiɝ stoʊnmeɪsɑnz lɛft ɪz kəz ɡɔlʒɹiən stɑpt peɪɪŋ ðɛm, ɪksɛpt wɪð pɹɑməsəz. aɪ kɛp tɛlɪŋ əm aɪ dɪdnt noʊ ɛniθɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt, bʌt hæf ə ðɛm sim tə θɪŋk ðəɾ aɪ wɑz laɪɪŋ, ən ði ʌðɝ hæf ðəɾ aɪ wɑz hɪntɪŋ ət sʌmθɪŋ."

Loial's grin almost split his face. "There you are. Rand, I was never so glad to get away from anyone as from those people upstairs. They kept asking me if the Ogier were coming back, and if Galldrian had agreed to pay what was owed. It seems the reason all the Ogier stonemasons left is because Galldrian stopped paying them, except with promises. I kept telling them I didn't know anything about it, but half of them seemed to think that I was lying, and the other half that I was hinting at something."

"wil bi aʊɾ ə hɪɹ sun," ɹænd əʃʊɹd hɪm. "mæt, ɑɹ jə ɔl ɹaɪt?" hɪz fɹɛnz feɪs lʊk mɔɹ hɑloʊ-tʃik ðən i ɹɪmɛmbɝd, ivən bæk ət ði ɪn, ən ɪz tʃikboʊnz mɔɹ pɹɑmənənt.

"We'll be out of here soon," Rand assured him. "Mat, are you all right?" His friend's face looked more hollow-cheeked than he remembered, even back at the inn, and his cheekbones more prominent.

"aɪ fil faɪn," mæt sɛd ɡɹʌmpəli, "bʌɾ aɪ sɝɾənli dɪdn əv ɛni tʃɹʌbəl livɪŋ ði ʌðɝ sɝvəns. ðə wʌnz u wɝn æskɪŋ ɪf jə stɑɹv mi θɔɾ aɪ wɑz sɪk ən dɪdnt wɑnə kʌm tu kloʊs."

"I feel fine," Mat said grumpily, "but I certainly didn't have any trouble leaving the other servants. The ones who weren't asking if you starved me thought I was sick and didn't want to come too close."

"hæv jə sɛns ðə dæɡɝ?" ɹænd æskt.

"Have you sensed the dagger?" Rand asked.

mæt ʃʊk ɪz hɛd ɡlʌmli. "ði oʊnli θɪŋ aɪv sɛnst ɪz ðət sʌmbɑɾiz wɑtʃɪŋ mi, moʊst ə ðə taɪm. ðiz pipəl ɑɹ əz bæɾ əz feɪdz fəɹ snikɪŋ ɝaʊnd. bɝn mi, aɪ nɪɹli dʒʌmpt aʊɾ ə maɪ skɪn wən hʊɹɪn toʊl mi hid loʊkeɪɾəd ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz' tʃɹeɪl. ɹænd, aɪ kæn fil ɪɾ əɾ ɔl, ən aɪv bɪn θɹu ðɪs blʌɾi bɪldɪŋ fɹəm ɹæftɝz tə beɪsmənt."

Mat shook his head glumly. "The only thing I've sensed is that somebody's watching me, most of the time. These people are as bad as Fades for sneaking around. Burn me, I nearly jumped out of my skin when Hurin told me he'd located the Darkfriends' trail. Rand, I can't feel it at all, and I've been through this bloody building from rafters to basement."

"ðæt dʌz nɑt min ɪɾ ɪzən hɪɹ, mæt. aɪ pʊɾ ɪɾ ɪn ðə tʃɛst wɪð ðə hɔɹn, ɹɪmɛmbɝ. meɪbi ðət kips jə fɹəm filɪŋ ɪt. aɪ doʊn θɪŋk feɪn noʊz haʊ tə oʊpən ɪt, ɛls hid nɑɾ əv ɡɔn tə ðə tʃɹʌbəl ə kæɹiɪŋ ðə weɪt wən i flɛd fæl dæɹə. ivən ðət mʌtʃ ɡoʊld ɪzən ɪmpɔɹɾənt bɪsaɪd ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ. wən wi faɪn ðə hɔɹn, wɪl faɪn ðə dæɡɝ. jəl si."

"That does not mean it isn't here, Mat. I put it in the chest with the Horn, remember. Maybe that keeps you from feeling it. I don't think Fain knows how to open it, else he'd not have gone to the trouble of carrying the weight when he fled Fal Dara. Even that much gold isn't important beside the Horn of Valere. When we find the Horn, we will find the dagger. You'll see."

"æz lɔŋ əz aɪ doʊn əv tə pɹitɛn tə bi jəɹ sɝvən ɛnimɔɹ," mæt mʌɾɝd. "æz lɔŋ əz jə doʊnt ɡoʊ mæɾ ænd. . . ." hi lɛt ðə wɝdz daɪ wɪð ə twɪst ə hɪz maʊθ.

"As long as I don't have to pretend to be your servant anymore," Mat muttered. "As long as you don't go mad and. . . ." He let the words die with a twist of his mouth.

"ɹæn ɪz nɑt mæd, mæt," lɔɪəl sɛd. "ðə kɛɹhinɪn wəd nɛvɝ əv lɛɾ ɪm ɪn hɪɹ ɪf i wɝ nɑɾ ə lɔɹd. ðeɪ ɑɹ ðə wʌnz u ɑɹ mæd."

"Rand is not mad, Mat," Loial said. "The Cairhienin would never have let him in here if he were not a lord. They are the ones who are mad."

"aɪm nɑt mæd," ɹænd sɛd hɑɹʃli. "nɑt jɛt. hʊɹɪn, ʃoʊ mi ðɪs ɡɑɹɾən."

"I'm not mad," Rand said harshly. "Not yet. Hurin, show me this garden."

"ðɪs weɪ, lɔɹd ɹænd."

"This way, Lord Rand."

ðeɪ wɛn aʊɾ ɪndə ðə naɪt baɪ ə smɔl dɔɹ ðət ɹænd hæd tə dʌk tə ɡɛt θɹu; lɔɪəl wɑz fɔɹs tə bɛn oʊvɝ ən hʌntʃ ɪz ʃoʊldɝz. ðəɹ wɑz ɪnʌf laɪɾ ɪn jɛloʊ pulz fɹəm ðə wɪndoʊz əbʌv fəɹ ɹænd tə meɪk aʊt bɹɪk wɔks bɪtwin skwɛɹ flaʊɝ bɛdz. ðə ʃædoʊz ə steɪbəlz ən ʌðɝ aʊtbɪldɪŋz bʌlkt ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs tə iðɝ saɪd. əkeɪʒənəl fɹæɡməns ə mjuzɪk dʒɹɪftəɾ aʊt, fɹəm ðə sɝvəns bɪloʊ əɹ fɹəm ðoʊz ɛntɝteɪnɪŋ ðɛɹ mæstɝz əbʌv.

They went out into the night by a small door that Rand had to duck to get through; Loial was forced to bend over and hunch his shoulders. There was enough light in yellow pools from the windows above for Rand to make out brick walks between square flower beds. The shadows of stables and other outbuildings bulked in the darkness to either side. Occasional fragments of music drifted out, from the servants below or from those entertaining their masters above.

hʊɹɪn lɛɾ əm əlɔŋ ðə wɔks əntɪl ivən ðə dɪm ɡloʊ feɪld ən ðeɪ meɪd ðɛɹ weɪ baɪ munlaɪɾ əloʊn, ðɛɹ buts kɹʌntʃɪŋ sɔfli ɑn ðə bɹɪk. bʊʃəz ðət wʊɾə bɪn bɹaɪt wɪð flaʊɝz baɪ deɪlaɪt naʊ meɪd stʃɹeɪnʒ hʌmps ɪn ðə dɑɹk. ɹænd fɪŋɡɝɾ ɪz sɔɹɾ ən dɪd nɑt lɛɾ ɪz aɪz steɪ ɑn ɛni wʌn spɑt tu lɔŋ. ə hʌnʒɹəd tʃɹɑləks kəd bi haɪɾɪŋ ɝaʊn əm ənsin. hi nu hʊɹɪn wʊɾə smɛl tʃɹɑləks ɪf ðeɪ wɝ ðɛɹ, bʌt ðət dɪd nɑt hɛlp ə ɡɹeɪt dil. ɪf bɑɹθeɪnz wɑz ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd, ðən ət list səm ə hɪz sɝvəns ən ɡɑɹdz hæd tə bi, tu, ən hʊɹɪn kəd nɑɾ ɔlweɪz smɛl ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd. dɑɹkfɹɛnz lipɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə naɪt wəd nɑt bi mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ ðən tʃɹɑləks.

Hurin led them along the walks until even the dim glow failed and they made their way by moonlight alone, their boots crunching softly on the brick. Bushes that would have been bright with flowers by daylight now made strange humps in the dark. Rand fingered his sword and did not let his eyes stay on any one spot too long. A hundred Trollocs could be hiding around them unseen. He knew Hurin would have smelled Trollocs if they were there, but that did not help a great deal. If Barthanes was a Darkfriend, then at least some of his servants and guards had to be, too, and Hurin could not always smell a Darkfriend. Darkfriends leaping out of the night would not be much better than Trollocs.

"ðɛɹ, lɔɹd ɹænd," hʊɹɪn wɪspɝd, pɔɪntɪŋ.

"There, Lord Rand," Hurin whispered, pointing.

əhɛd, stoʊn wɔlz nɑt mʌtʃ haɪɝ ðən lɔɪəlz hɛɾ ɛnkloʊzd ə skwɛɹ pɝhæps fɪfti peɪsɪz ɑn ə saɪd. ɹænd kəd nɑt bi ʃʊɹ, ɪn ðə ʃædoʊz, bʌɾ ɪt lʊkt əz ɪf ðə ɡɑɹɾənz stʃɹɛtʃt ɑn bɪɑn ðə wɔlz. hi wʌndɝd waɪ bɑɹθeɪnz hæd bɪlt ə wɔld ɛnkloʊʒɝ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə hɪz ɡɑɹɾən. noʊ ɹuf ʃoʊɾ əbʌv ðə wɔl. waɪ wəd ðeɪ ɡoʊ ɪn ðəɹ ən steɪ?

Ahead, stone walls not much higher than Loial's head enclosed a square perhaps fifty paces on a side. Rand could not be sure, in the shadows, but it looked as if the gardens stretched on beyond the walls. He wondered why Barthanes had built a walled enclosure in the middle of his garden. No roof showed above the wall. Why would they go in there and stay?

lɔɪəl bɛn tə pʊɾ ɪz maʊθ kloʊs tə ɹændz ɪɹ. "aɪ toʊl jə ðɪs wɑz ɔl ən oʊɡiɝ ɡɹoʊv, wʌns. ɹænd, ðə weɪɡeɪɾ ɪz wɪðɪn ðət wɔl. aɪ kən fil ɪt."

Loial bent to put his mouth close to Rand's ear. "I told you this was all an Ogier grove, once. Rand, the Waygate is within that wall. I can feel it."

ɹænd hɝd mæt saɪ dɪspɛɹɪŋli. "wi kænt ɡɪv ʌp, mæt," hi sɛd.

Rand heard Mat sigh despairingly. "We can't give up, Mat," he said.

"aɪm nɑt ɡɪvɪŋ ʌp. aɪ dʒʌst əv ɪnʌf bɹeɪnz nɑt tə wɑnə tʃɹævəl ðə weɪz əɡɛn."

"I'm not giving up. I just have enough brains not to want to travel the Ways again."

"wi meɪ hæv tə," ɹænd toʊl hɪm. "ɡoʊ faɪn ɪŋtʃɹ ən vɛɹɪn. ɡɛɾ əm əloʊn sʌmhaʊ - aɪ doʊn kɛɹ haʊ - ən tɛl əm aɪ θɪŋk feɪn əz teɪkən ðə hɔɹn θɹu ə weɪɡeɪt. dʒʌs doʊn lɛɾ ɛniwʌn ɛls hɪɹ. ən ɹɪmɛmbɝ tə lɪmp; jə ɑɹ səpoʊz tə hæv hæɾ ə fɔl." ɪt wɑz ə wʌndɝ tə hɪm ðəɾ ivən feɪn wəd ɹɪsk ðə weɪz, bʌɾ ɪt sim ði oʊnli ænsɝ. ðeɪ wʊdn spɛn ə deɪ ən ə naɪt dʒʌst sɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðɛɹ, wɪθaʊɾ ə ɹuf oʊvɝ ðɛɹ hɛdz.

"We may have to," Rand told him. "Go find Ingtar and Verin. Get them alone somehow - I don't care how - and tell them I think Fain has taken the Horn through a Waygate. Just don't let anyone else hear. And remember to limp; you are supposed to have had a fall." It was a wonder to him that even Fain would risk the Ways, but it seemed the only answer. They wouldn't spend a day and a night just sitting in there, without a roof over their heads.

mæt swɛpt ə loʊ baʊ, ən ɪz vɔɪs wɑz hɛvi wɪð sɑɹkæzəm. "æt wʌns, maɪ lɔɹd. əz maɪ lɔɹd wɪʃɪz. ʃæl aɪ kæɹi jəɹ bænɝ, maɪ lɔɹd?" hi stɑɹɾəd bæk fəɹ ðə mænɝ, hɪz ɡɹʌmbəlz feɪɾɪŋ əweɪ. "naʊ aɪ hæv tə lɪmp. nɛkst ɪɾəl bi ə bɹoʊkən nɛk, ɔɹ. . . ."

Mat swept a low bow, and his voice was heavy with sarcasm. "At once, my Lord. As my Lord wishes. Shall I carry your banner, my Lord?" He started back for the manor, his grumbles fading away. "Now I have to limp. Next it'll be a broken neck, or. . . ."

"hiz dʒʌst wɝiɾ əbaʊt ðə dæɡɝ, ɹænd," lɔɪəl sɛd.

"He's just worried about the dagger, Rand," Loial said.

"aɪ noʊ," ɹænd sɛd. bʌt haʊ lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ i tɛlz sʌmbɑɾi wʌɾ aɪ æm, nɑɾ ivən minɪŋ tə? hi kəd nɑt bɪliv mæt wəd bɪtʃɹeɪ hɪm ɑn pɝpəs; ðəɹ wɑz ðət mʌtʃ ə ðɛɹ fɹɛndʃɪp lɛft, ət list. "lɔɪəl, bus mi ʌp wɛɹ aɪ kən si oʊvɝ ðə wɔl."

"I know," Rand said. But how long before he tells somebody what I am, not even meaning to? He could not believe Mat would betray him on purpose; there was that much of their friendship left, at least. "Loial, boost me up where I can see over the wall."

"ɹænd, ɪf ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz ɑɹ stɪl - "

"Rand, if the Darkfriends are still - "

"ðeɪ ɑɹənt. bus mi ʌp, lɔɪəl."

"They aren't. Boost me up, Loial."

ðə θɹi ʌv əm muv kloʊs tə ðə wɔl, ən lɔɪəl meɪɾ ə stɝəp wɪð ɪz hænz fəɹ ɹændz fʊt. ði oʊɡiɝ stʃɹeɪɾənd izəli wɪð ðə weɪt, lɪftɪŋ ɹændz hɛd dʒʌs haɪ ɪnʌf tə si oʊvɝ ðə tɑp ə ðə wɔl.

The three of them moved close to the wall, and Loial made a stirrup with his hands for Rand's foot. The Ogier straightened easily with the weight, lifting Rand's head just high enough to see over the top of the wall.

ðə θɪn, weɪnɪŋ mun ɡeɪv lɪɾəl laɪt, ən moʊst ə ði ɛɹiə wɑz ɪn ʃædoʊ, bʌt ðəɹ dɪd nɑt sim tə bi ɛni flaʊɝz əɹ ʃɹʌbz ɪnsaɪd ðə wɔl skwɛɹ. oʊnli ə loʊn bɛntʃ ə peɪl mɑɹbəl, pleɪst əz ɪf wʌn mæn maɪt sɪɾ ɑn ɪt tə stɛɹ ət wʌt stʊɾ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə speɪs laɪk ə hjudʒ əpɹaɪt stoʊn slæb.

The thin, waning moon gave little light, and most of the area was in shadow, but there did not seem to be any flowers or shrubs inside the walled square. Only a lone bench of pale marble, placed as if one man might sit on it to stare at what stood in the middle of the space like a huge upright stone slab.

ɹænd kɑt ðə tɑp ə ðə wɔl ən pʊl hɪmsɛlf ʌp. lɔɪəl ɡeɪv ə loʊ st ən ɡɹæbd əɾ ɪz fʊt, bʌɾ i dʒɝk fɹi ən ɹoʊld oʊvɝ ðə wɔl, dʒɹɑpɪŋ ɪnsaɪd. ðəɹ wɑz kloʊs-kɹɑpt ɡɹæs ʌndɝ ɪz fit; hi θɔt veɪɡli ðət bɑɹθeɪnz mʌs lɛt ʃip ɪn, ət list. stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə ʃæɾoʊd stoʊn slæb, ðə weɪɡeɪt, hi wɑz stɑɹɾəld tə hɪɹ buts θʌmp tə ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪsaɪd hɪm.

Rand caught the top of the wall and pulled himself up. Loial gave a low hsst and grabbed at his foot, but he jerked free and rolled over the wall, dropping inside. There was close-cropped grass under his feet; he thought vaguely that Barthanes must let sheep in, at least. Staring at the shadowed stone slab, the Waygate, he was startled to hear boots thump to the ground beside him.

hʊɹɪn klaɪm tə hɪz fit, dʌstɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ɔf. "ju ʃəd bi kɛɹfəl duɪŋ ðæt, lɔɹd ɹænd. kəd bi ɛnibəɾi haɪɾɪŋ ɪn hɪɹ. əɹ ɛniθɪŋ." hi pɪɹɾ ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs wɪðɪn ðə wɔlz, filɪŋ əɾ ɪz bɛlt əz ɪf fəɹ ðə ʃɔɹt sɔɹɾ ən sɔɹd-bɹeɪkɝ i hæd hæd tə liv ət ði ɪn; sɝvəns dɪd nɑt ɡoʊ ɑɹmd ɪn kɛɹhin. "dʒʌmp ɪn ə hoʊl wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ, ən ðɛɹəl bi ə sneɪk ɪn ɪɾ ɛvɹi taɪm."

Hurin climbed to his feet, dusting himself off. "You should be careful doing that, Lord Rand. Could be anybody hiding in here. Or anything." He peered into the darkness within the walls, feeling at his belt as if for the short sword and sword-breaker he had had to leave at the inn; servants did not go armed in Cairhien. "Jump in a hole without looking, and there'll be a snake in it every time."

"ju wəd smɛl ðɛm," ɹænd sɛd.

"You would smell them," Rand said.

"meɪbi." ðə snɪfɝ ɪnheɪl dipli. "bʌɾ aɪ kən oʊnli smɛl wʌt ðeɪv dʌn, nɑt wʌt ðeɪ ɪntɛnd."

"Maybe." The sniffer inhaled deeply. "But I can only smell what they've done, not what they intend."

ðəɹ wɑz ə skɹeɪpɪŋ saʊn fɹəm oʊvɝ ɹændz hɛd, ən ðən lɔɪəl wɑz lɛɾɪŋ hɪmsɛlf daʊn fɹəm ðə wɔl. ði oʊɡiɝ dɪd nɑɾ ivən əv tə stʃɹeɪɾən ɪz ɑɹmz kəmplitli bɪfɔɹ ɪz buts tʌtʃt ðə ɡɹaʊnd. "ɹæʃ," hi mʌɾɝd. "ju hjumənz ɑɹ ɔlweɪz soʊ ɹæʃ ən heɪsti. ən naʊ juv mi duɪŋ ɪt. ɛldɝ heɪmən wəd spik tə mi səvɪɹli, ən maɪ mʌðɝ. . . ." ðə dɑɹknəs hɪɾ ɪz feɪs, bʌt ɹænd wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪz ɪɹz wɝ twɪtʃɪŋ vɪɡɝəsli. "ɹænd, ɪf jə doʊn stɑɹt biɪŋ ə lɪɾəl kɛɹfəl, jə ɑɹ gɑnə ɡɛt mi ɪn tʃɹʌbəl."

There was a scraping sound from over Rand's head, and then Loial was letting himself down from the wall. The Ogier did not even have to straighten his arms completely before his boots touched the ground. "Rash," he muttered. "You humans are always so rash and hasty. And now you have me doing it. Elder Haman would speak to me severely, and my mother. . . ." The darkness hid his face, but Rand was sure his ears were twitching vigorously. "Rand, if you don't start being a little careful, you are going to get me in trouble."

ɹænd wɔk tə ðə weɪɡeɪt, wɔkt ɔl ðə weɪ ɝaʊn ɪt. ivən kloʊs ʌp ɪt lʊk laɪk nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ ðən ə θɪk skwɛɹ ə stoʊn, tɔlɝ ðən i wɑz. ðə bæk wɑz smuð ən kul tə ðə tʌtʃ - hi oʊnli bɹʌʃt ɪz hæn əɡɛnst ɪt kwɪkli - bʌt ðə fɹʌn hæd bɪn kɑɹv baɪ ən ɑɹɾəsts hænz. vaɪnz, livz, ən flaʊɝz kʌvɝɾ ɪt, itʃ soʊ faɪnli dʌn ðəɾ ɪn ðə dɪm munlaɪt ðeɪ simd ɔlmoʊst ɹil. hi fɛl ðə ɡɹaʊn ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɪt; ðə ɡɹæs hæd bɪn skɹeɪpt pɑɹtli əweɪ ɪn tu ɑɹks sətʃ əz ðoʊz ɡeɪts wəd meɪk ɪn oʊpənɪŋ.

Rand walked to the Waygate, walked all the way around it. Even close up it looked like nothing more than a thick square of stone, taller than he was. The back was smooth and cool to the touch - he only brushed his hand against it quickly - but the front had been carved by an artist's hands. Vines, leaves, and flowers covered it, each so finely done that in the dim moonlight they seemed almost real. He felt the ground in front of it; the grass had been scraped partly away in two arcs such as those gates would make in opening.

"ɪz ðəɾ ə weɪɡeɪt?" hʊɹɪn æskt ənsɝteɪnli. "aɪv hɝd tɛl ə ðɛm, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt. . . ." hi snɪf ði ɛɹ. "ðə tʃɹeɪl ɡoʊz ɹaɪt tə ɪɾ ən stɑps, lɔɹd ɹænd. haʊ ɑɹ wi gɑnə fɑloʊ ðɛm, naʊ? aɪv hɝɾ ɪf jə ɡoʊ θɹu ə weɪɡeɪt, jə kʌm aʊt mæd, ɪf jə kʌm aʊɾ əɾ ɔl."

"Is that a Waygate?" Hurin asked uncertainly. "I've heard tell of them, of course, but. . . ." He sniffed the air. "The trail goes right to it and stops, Lord Rand. How are we going to follow them, now? I've heard if you go through a Waygate, you come out mad, if you come out at all."

"ɪt kən bi dʌn, hʊɹɪn. aɪv dʌn ɪt, ən lɔɪəl, ən mæt ən pɛɹɪn." ɹænd nɛvɝ tʊk ɪz aɪz fɹəm ðə tæŋɡəlz ə livz ɑn ðə stoʊn. ðəɹ wɑz wʌn ənlaɪk ɛni ʌðɝ kɑɹv ðɛɹ, hi nu. ðə tʃɹɛfɔɪl lif ə feɪbəld ɑvɛndɪsɔɹə, ðə tʃɹi ʌv laɪf. hi pʊɾ ɪz hæn ɑn ɪt. "aɪl bɛt jə kən smɛl ðɛɹ tʃɹeɪl əlɔŋ ðə weɪz. wi kən fɑloʊ ɛniwɛɹ ðeɪ kən ɹʌn." ɪt wəd nɑt hɝt tə pɹuv tə hɪmsɛlf ðəɾ i kəd meɪk hɪmsɛlf stɛp θɹu ə weɪɡeɪt. "aɪl pɹuv ɪt tə ju." hi hɝd hʊɹɪn ɡɹoʊn. ðə lif wɑz wɝkt ɪn ðə stoʊn dʒʌst əz ði ʌðɝz wɝ, bʌɾ ɪt keɪm əweɪ ɪn ɪz hænd. lɔɪəl ɡɹoʊnd, tu.

"It can be done, Hurin. I've done it, and Loial, and Mat and Perrin." Rand never took his eyes from the tangles of leaves on the stone. There was one unlike any other carved there, he knew. The trefoil leaf of fabled Avendesora, the Tree of Life. He put his hand on it. "I'll bet you can smell their trail along the Ways. We can follow anywhere they can run." It would not hurt to prove to himself that he could make himself step through a Waygate. "I'll prove it to you." He heard Hurin groan. The leaf was worked in the stone just as the others were, but it came away in his hand. Loial groaned, too.

ɪn ən ɪnstən ði ɪluʒən ə lɪvɪŋ plæns sim sʌɾənli ɹil. stoʊn livz əpɪɹd tə stɝ wɪð ə bɹiz, flaʊɝz əpɪɹd tə hæv kʌlɝ ivən ɪn ðə dɑɹk. daʊn ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə mæs ə laɪn əpɪɹd, ən ðə tu hævz ə ðə slæb swʌŋ sloʊli təwɔɹd ɹænd. hi stɛp bæk tə lɛɾ əm oʊpən. hi dɪd nɑt faɪn hɪmsɛlf lʊkɪŋ ət ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə wɔl skwɛɹ, bʌt niðɝ dɪɾ i si ðə dʌl sɪlvɝ ɹəflɛkʃən i ɹɪmɛmbɝd. ðə speɪs bɪtwin ði oʊpənɪŋ ɡeɪts wɑz ə blæk soʊ dɑɹk ɪt sim tə meɪk ðə naɪɾ ɝaʊn ɪt laɪɾɝ. ðə pɪtʃ-blæknəs uzd aʊt bɪtwin ðə stɪl-muvɪŋ ɡeɪts.

In an instant the illusion of living plants seemed suddenly real. Stone leaves appeared to stir with a breeze, flowers appeared to have color even in the dark. Down the center of the mass a line appeared, and the two halves of the slab swung slowly toward Rand. He stepped back to let them open. He did not find himself looking at the other side of the walled square, but neither did he see the dull silver reflection he remembered. The space between the opening gates was a black so dark it seemed to make the night around it lighter. The pitch-blackness oozed out between the still-moving gates.

ɹænd lɛp bæk wɪð ə ʃaʊt, dʒɹɑpɪŋ ði ɑvɛndɪsɔɹə lif ɪn ɪz heɪst, ən lɔɪəl kɹaɪɾ aʊt, "mætʃɪn ʃɪn. ðə blæk wɪnd."

Rand leaped back with a shout, dropping the Avendesora leaf in his haste, and Loial cried out, "Machin Shin. The Black Wind."

ðə saʊn ʌv wɪn fɪl ðɛɹ ɪɹz; ðə ɡɹæs stɝɾ ɪn ɹɪpəlz təwɔɹd ðə wɔlz, ən dɝt swɝld ʌp, sʌkt ɪndə ði ɛɹ. ən ɪn ðə wɪn ə θaʊzən ɪnseɪn vɔɪsəz sim tə kɹaɪ, tɛn θaʊzənd, oʊvɝlæpɪŋ, dʒɹaʊnɪŋ itʃ ʌðɝ. ɹænd kəd meɪk aʊt səm ə ðɛm, ðoʊ hi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə.

The sound of wind filled their ears; the grass stirred in ripples toward the walls, and dirt swirled up, sucked into the air. And in the wind a thousand insane voices seemed to cry, ten thousand, overlapping, drowning each other. Rand could make out some of them, though he tried not to.

. . . blʌd soʊ swit, soʊ swit tə dʒɹɪŋk ðə blʌd, ðə blʌd ðət dʒɹɪps, dʒɹɪps, dʒɹɑps soʊ ɹɛd; pɹɪɾi aɪz, faɪn aɪz, aɪ hæv noʊ aɪz, plʌk ði aɪz fɹəm aʊɾ ə jəɹ hɛd; ɡɹaɪn jəɹ boʊnz, splɪt jəɹ boʊnz ɪnsaɪd jəɹ flɛʃ, sʌk jəɹ mɛɹoʊ waɪl jə skɹim; skɹim, skɹim, sɪŋɪŋ skɹimz, sɪŋ jəɹ skɹimz. . . . ən wɝst ʌv ɔl, ə wɪspɝɪŋ θɹɛd θɹu ɔl ðə ɹɛst. ælθɹ. ælθɹ. ælθɹ.

. . . blood so sweet, so sweet to drink the blood, the blood that drips, drips, drops so red; pretty eyes, fine eyes, I have no eyes, pluck the eyes from out of your head; grind your bones, split your bones inside your flesh, suck your marrow while you scream; scream, scream, singing screams, sing your screams. . . . And worst of all, a whispering thread through all the rest. Al'Thor. Al'Thor. Al'Thor.

ɹænd faʊn ðə vɔɪɾ ɝaʊn ɪm ən ɛmbɹeɪst ɪt, nɛvɝ maɪndɪŋ ðə tæntəlaɪzɪŋ, sɪkənɪŋ ɡloʊ ʌv seɪɾɪn dʒʌst aʊɾ ə hɪz saɪt. ɡɹeɪɾəst ʌv ɔl ðə deɪnʒɝz əlɔŋ ðə weɪz wɑz ðə blæk wɪn ðət tʊk ðə soʊlz ə ðoʊz ɪt kɪld, ən dʒɹoʊv mæd ðoʊz ɪt lɛt lɪv, bʌt mætʃɪn ʃɪn wɑz ə pɑɹɾ ə ðə weɪz; ɪt kəd nɑt liv ðɛm. oʊnli ɪt wɑz floʊɪŋ ɪndə ðə naɪt, ən ðə blæk wɪn kɔld ɪz neɪm.

Rand found the void around him and embraced it, never minding the tantalizing, sickening glow of saidin just out of his sight. Greatest of all the dangers along the Ways was the Black Wind that took the souls of those it killed, and drove mad those it let live, but Machin Shin was a part of the Ways; it could not leave them. Only it was flowing into the night, and the Black Wind called his name.

ðə weɪɡeɪt wɑz nɑt jɛt fʊli oʊpən. ɪf ðeɪ kəɾ oʊnli pʊt ði ɑvɛndɪsɔɹə lif bæk. . . . hi sɔ lɔɪəl skɹæmbəlɪŋ ɑn ɪz hænz ən niz, fʌmbəlɪŋ ən sɝtʃɪŋ ðə ɡɹæs ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs.

The Waygate was not yet fully open. If they could only put the Avendesora leaf back. . . . He saw Loial scrambling on his hands and knees, fumbling and searching the grass in the darkness.

seɪɾɪn fɪl hɪm. hi fɛlt əz ɪf ɪz boʊnz wɝ vaɪbɹeɪɾɪŋ, fɛl ðə ɹɛd-hɑt, aɪs-koʊl floʊ ʌv ðə wʌn paʊɝ, fɛl tʃɹuli əlaɪv əz i nɛvɝ wɑz wɪθaʊɾ ɪt, fɛl ði ɔɪl-slɪk teɪnt. . . . noʊ! ən saɪlənli hi skɹim bæk ət hɪmsɛlf fɹəm bɪɑn ði ɛmptinəs, ɪts kʌmɪŋ fəɹ ju! ɪɾəl kɪl ɔl ʌv ʌs! hi hɝld ɪɾ ɔl ət ðə blæk bʌlʒ, stændɪŋ aʊɾ ə fʊl spæn fɹəm ðə weɪɡeɪt, naʊ. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðəɾ i hɝld, əɹ haʊ, bʌɾ ɪn ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðət dɑɹknəs blumd ə kɔɹʌskeɪɾɪŋ faʊntən ə laɪt.

Saidin filled him. He felt as if his bones were vibrating, felt the red-hot, ice-cold flow of the One Power, felt truly alive as he never was without it, felt the oil-slick taint. . . . No! And silently he screamed back at himself from beyond the emptiness, It's coming for you! It'll kill all of us! He hurled it all at the black bulge, standing out a full span from the Waygate, now. He did not know what it was that he hurled, or how, but in the heart of that darkness bloomed a coruscating fountain of light.

ðə blæk wɪnd ʃɹikt, tɛn θaʊzənd wɝdləs haʊlz ʌv æɡəni. sloʊli, ɡɪvɪŋ weɪ ɪntʃ baɪ ɹɪlʌktən ɪntʃ, ðə bʌlʒ lɛsənd; sloʊli ði uzɪŋ ɹɪvɝst, bæk ɪndə ðə stɪl-oʊpən weɪɡeɪt.

The Black Wind shrieked, ten thousand wordless howls of agony. Slowly, giving way inch by reluctant inch, the bulge lessened; slowly the oozing reversed, back into the still-open Waygate.

ðə paʊɝ ɹeɪs θɹu ɹænd ɪn ə tɔɹənt. hi kəd fil ðə lɪŋk bɪtwin hɪmsɛlf ən seɪɾɪn, laɪk ə ɹɪvɝ ɪn flʌd, bɪtwin hɪmsɛlf ən ðə pjʊɹ faɪɝ bleɪzɪŋ ɪn ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə blæk waɪnd, ə ɹeɪdʒɪŋ kæɾɝækt. ðə hiɾ ɪnsaɪɾ ɪm wɛn tə waɪt-hit, ən bɪɑnd, tə ə ʃɪmɝ ðət wʊɾə mɛltəd stoʊn ən veɪpɝaɪz stil ən meɪd ði ɛɹ bɝst ɪndə fleɪm. ðə koʊld ɡɹu tɪl ðə bɹɛθ ɪn ɪz lʌŋz ʃʊɾə fɹoʊzən sɑləɾ ən hɑɹɾ əz mɛɾəl. hi kəd fil ɪɾ oʊvɝwɛlmɪŋ hɪm, fil laɪf ɪɹoʊɾɪŋ laɪk ə sɑf kleɪ ɹɪvɝbæŋk, fil wʌt wɑz ɪm wɛɹɪŋ əweɪ.

The Power raced through Rand in a torrent. He could feel the link between himself and saidin, like a river in flood, between himself and the pure fire blazing in the heart of the Black Wind, a raging cataract. The heat inside him went to white-heat, and beyond, to a shimmer that would have melted stone and vaporized steel and made the air burst into flame. The cold grew till the breath in his lungs should have frozen solid and hard as metal. He could feel it overwhelming him, feel life eroding like a soft clay riverbank, feel what was him wearing away.

kæn stɑp! ɪf ɪt ɡɛts aʊt. . . . hæv tə kɪl ɪt! aɪ - kən - nɑt - stɑp! dɛspɝətli hi klʌŋ tə fɹæɡmɛns ə hɪmsɛlf. ðə wʌn paʊɝ ɹɔɹd θɹu hɪm; hi ɹoʊɾ ɪt laɪk ə tʃɪp ʌv wʊɾ ɪn ɹæpədz. ðə vɔɪd bɪɡæn tə mɛlt ən floʊ; ði ɛmptinəs stimd wɪð fɹizɪŋ koʊld.

Can't stop! If it gets out. . . . Have to kill it! I - can - not - stop! Desperately he clung to fragments of himself. The One Power roared through him; he rode it like a chip of wood in rapids. The void began to melt and flow; the emptiness steamed with freezing cold.

ðə moʊʃən ə ðə weɪɡeɪt hɔltəd, ən ɹɪvɝst.

The motion of the Waygate halted, and reversed.

ɹænd stɛɹd, ʃʊɹ, ɪn ðə dɪm θɔts floʊɾɪŋ aʊtsaɪd ðə vɔɪd, ðəɾ i wɑz oʊnli siɪŋ wʌɾ i wɑntəd tə si.

Rand stared, sure, in the dim thoughts floating outside the void, that he was only seeing what he wanted to see.

ðə ɡeɪts dʒɹɪftəd kloʊsɝ təɡɛðɝ, pʊʃɪŋ bæk mætʃɪn ʃɪn əz ɪf ðə blæk wɪn hæd sɑləd sʌbstəns. ði ɪnfɝnoʊ stɪl ɹɔɹɾ ɪn ɪts bɹɛst.

The gates drifted closer together, pushing back Machin Shin as if the Black Wind had solid substance. The inferno still roared in its breast.

wɪð ə veɪɡ, dɪstənt wʌndɝɪŋ, ɹænd sɔ lɔɪəl, stɪl ɑn hænz ən niz, bækɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðə kloʊzɪŋ ɡeɪts.

With a vague, distant wondering, Rand saw Loial, still on hands and knees, backing away from the closing gates.

ðə ɡæp nɛɹoʊd, vænɪʃt. ðə livz ən vaɪnz mɝdʒd ɪndə ə sɑləd wɔl, ən wɝ stoʊn.

The gap narrowed, vanished. The leaves and vines merged into a solid wall, and were stone.

ɹænd fɛl ðə lɪŋk bɪtwin ɪm ən ðə faɪɝ snæp, ðə floʊ ʌv paʊɝ θɹu hɪm sis. ə moʊmən mɔɹ, ən ɪt wʊɾə swɛpt ɪm əweɪ kəmplitli. ʃeɪkɪŋ, hi dʒɹɑp tə hɪz niz. ɪt wɑz stɪl ðəɹ ɪnsaɪd. seɪɾɪn. noʊ lɔŋɡɝ floʊɪŋ, bʌt ðɛɹ, ɪn ə pul. hi wɑz ə pul ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ. hi tʃɹɛmbəld wɪð ɪt. hi kəd smɛl ðə ɡɹæs, ðə dɝt bɪniθ, ðə stoʊn ə ðə wɔlz. ivən ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs i kəd si itʃ bleɪɾ ʌv ɡɹæs, sɛpɹəɾ ən hoʊl, ɔl ə ðɛm ət wʌns. hi kəd fil itʃ mɪnut stɝɪŋ ə ði ɛɹ ɑn ɪz feɪs. hɪz tʌŋ kɝɾəld wɪð ðə teɪst ə ðə teɪnt; hɪz stʌmək nɑɾɪd ən spæzmd.

Rand felt the link between him and the fire snap, the flow of Power through him cease. A moment more, and it would have swept him away completely. Shaking, he dropped to his knees. It was still there inside. Saidin. No longer flowing, but there, in a pool. He was a pool of the One Power. He trembled with it. He could smell the grass, the dirt beneath, the stone of the walls. Even in the darkness he could see each blade of grass, separate and whole, all of them at once. He could feel each minute stirring of the air on his face. His tongue curdled with the taste of the taint; his stomach knotted and spasmed.

fɹæntəkəli hi klɔɾ ɪz weɪ aʊɾ ə ðə vɔɪd; stɪl ɑn ɪz niz, nɑt muvɪŋ, hi fɔt fɹi. ən ðən ɔl ðət wɑz lɛft wɑz ðə feɪɾɪŋ faʊlnəs ɑn ɪz tʌŋ, ən ðə kɹæmpɪŋ ɪn ɪz stʌmək, ən ðə mɛmɹi. soʊ - əlaɪv.

Frantically he clawed his way out of the void; still on his knees, not moving, he fought free. And then all that was left was the fading foulness on his tongue, and the cramping in his stomach, and the memory. So - alive.

"ju seɪvd ʌs, bɪldɝ." hʊɹɪn hæɾ ɪz bæk pɹɛst əɡɛns ðə wɔl, ən ɪz vɔɪs wɑz hɔɹs. "ðæt θɪŋ - ðət wɑz ðə blæk waɪnd? - ɪt wɑz wɝs ðən - wɑz ɪt gɑnə hɝl ðət faɪɝ əɾ ʌs? lɔɹd ɹænd! dɪɾ ɪt hɑɹm ju? dɪɾ ɪt tʌtʃ ju?" hi keɪm ɹʌnɪŋ əz ɹænd ɡɑt tə hɪz fit, hɛlpɪŋ ɪm ðə læs bɪt. lɔɪəl wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ ʌp, tu, dʌstɪŋ ɪz hænz ən ɪz niz.

"You saved us, Builder." Hurin had his back pressed against the wall, and his voice was hoarse. "That thing - that was the Black Wind? - it was worse than - was it going to hurl that fire at us? Lord Rand! Did it harm you? Did it touch you?" He came running as Rand got to his feet, helping him the last bit. Loial was getting up, too, dusting his hands and his knees.

"wil nɛvɝ fɑloʊ feɪn θɹu ðæt." ɹænd tʌtʃt lɔɪəlz ɑɹm. "θæŋk ju. jə dɪd seɪv ʌs." jə seɪv mi, ət list. ɪt wɑz kɪlɪŋ mi. kɪlɪŋ mi, ən ɪt fɛlt - wʌndɝfəl. hi swɑloʊd; ə feɪn tʃɹeɪs ə ðə teɪst stɪl koʊɾəd ɪz maʊθ. "aɪ wɑn sʌmθɪŋ tə dʒɹɪŋk."

"We'll never follow Fain through that." Rand touched Loial's arm. "Thank you. You did save us." You saved me, at least. It was killing me. Killing me, and it felt - wonderful. He swallowed; a faint trace of the taste still coated his mouth. "I want something to drink."

"aɪ oʊnli faʊn ðə lif ən pʊɾ ɪt bæk," lɔɪəl sɛd, ʃɹʌɡɪŋ. "ɪt sim ðəɾ ɪf wi kəd nɑt ɡɛt ðə weɪɡeɪt kloʊzd, ɪt wəd kɪl ʌs. aɪm əfɹeɪɾ aɪm nɑɾ ə vɛɹi ɡʊd hɪɹoʊ, ɹænd. aɪ wɑz soʊ əfɹeɪɾ aɪ kəd hɑɹdli θɪŋk."

"I only found the leaf and put it back," Loial said, shrugging. "It seemed that if we could not get the Waygate closed, it would kill us. I am afraid I'm not a very good hero, Rand. I was so afraid I could hardly think."

"wi wɝ boʊθ əfɹeɪd," ɹænd sɛd. "wi meɪ bi ə pʊɹ pɛɹ ə hɪɹoʊz, bʌt wəɹ wʌt ðəɹ ɪz. ɪts ə ɡʊd θɪŋ ɪŋtʃɹ ɪz wɪð ʌs."

"We were both afraid," Rand said. "We may be a poor pair of heroes, but we are what there is. It's a good thing Ingtar is with us."

"lɔɹd ɹænd," hʊɹɪn sɛd dɪfəɾəntli, "kʊd wi - liv, naʊ?"

"Lord Rand," Hurin said diffidently, "could we - leave, now?"

ðə snɪfɝ meɪɾ ə fʌs əbaʊt ɹænd ɡoʊɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə wɔl fɝst, wɪð nɑt noʊɪŋ u wɑz weɪɾɪŋ aʊtsaɪd, əntɪl ɹænd pɔɪntəɾ aʊt ðəɾ i hæd ði oʊnli wɛpən əmʌŋ ðɛm. ivən ðən hʊɹɪn dɪd nɑt sim tə laɪk lɛɾɪŋ lɔɪəl lɪft ɹænd tə kætʃ ðə tɑp ə ðə wɔl ən pʊl hɪmsɛlf oʊvɝ.

The sniffer made a fuss about Rand going over the wall first, with not knowing who was waiting outside, until Rand pointed out that he had the only weapon among them. Even then Hurin did not seem to like letting Loial lift Rand to catch the top of the wall and pull himself over.

ɹænd lændəɾ ɑn ɪz fit wɪð ə θʌd, lɪsnɪŋ ən piɹɪŋ ɪndə ðə naɪt. fəɹ ə moʊmən i θɔɾ i sɔ sʌmθɪŋ muv, hɝɾ ə but skɹeɪp ɑn ðə bɹɪk wɔk, bʌt niðɝ wɑz ɹɪpiɾɪd, ən i dɪsmɪst ɪɾ əz nɝvəsnəs. hi θɔt ðəɾ i hæɾ ə ɹaɪt tə bi nɝvəs. hi tɝn tə hɛlp hʊɹɪn daʊn.

Rand landed on his feet with a thud, listening and peering into the night. For a moment he thought he saw something move, heard a boot scrape on the brick walk, but neither was repeated, and he dismissed it as nervousness. He thought that he had a right to be nervous. He turned to help Hurin down.

"lɔɹd ɹænd," ðə snɪfɝ sɛɾ əz sun əz ɪz fit wɝ sɑlədli ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, "haʊ ɑɹ wi gɑnə fɑloʊ ðɛm naʊ? fɹəm wʌɾ aɪv hɝɾ ə ðoʊz θɪŋz, ðə hoʊl lɑɾ ə ðɛm kəd bi hæfweɪ əkɹɔs ðə wɝl baɪ naʊ, ɪn ɛni dɝɛkʃən."

"Lord Rand," the sniffer said as soon as his feet were solidly on the ground, "how are we going to follow them now? From what I've heard of those things, the whole lot of them could be halfway across the world by now, in any direction."

"vɛɹɪn wɪl noʊ ə weɪ." ɹænd sʌɾənli wɑntəd tə læf; tə faɪn ðə hɔɹn ən ðə dæɡɝ - ɪf ðeɪ kəd bi faʊnd, naʊ - hi hæd tə ɡoʊ bæk tə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðeɪ hæd lɛɾ ɪm lus, ən naʊ hi hæd tə ɡoʊ bæk. "aɪ woʊn lɛt mæt daɪ wɪθaʊt tʃɹaɪɪŋ."

"Verin will know a way." Rand suddenly wanted to laugh; to find the Horn and the dagger - if they could be found, now - he had to go back to the Aes Sedai. They had let him loose, and now he had to go back. "I won't let Mat die without trying."

lɔɪəl dʒɔɪn ðɛm, ən ðeɪ wɛn bæk təwɔɹd ðə mænɝ, tə bi mɛɾ ət ðə smɔl dɔɹ baɪ mæt, hu oʊpən ɪt dʒʌst əz ɹænd ɹitʃt fəɹ ðə hændəl. "vɛɹɪn sɛz jəɹ nɑt tə də ɛniθɪŋ. ɪf hʊɹɪnz faʊnd wɛɹ ðə hɔɹn ɪz kɛpt, ðən ʃi sɛz ðæts ɔl wi kən du, naʊ. ʃi sɛz wɪl liv əz sun əz jə kʌm bæk, ən meɪk ə plæn. ən aɪ seɪ ðɪs ɪz ðə læs taɪm aɪ ɡoʊ ɹʌnɪŋ bæk ən fɔɹθ wɪð mɛsədʒəz. ɪf jə wɑnə seɪ sʌmθɪŋ tə sʌmbɑɾi, jə kən tɔk tə ðɛm jɝsɛlf fɹəm naʊ ɑn." mæt pɪɹd pæst əm ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs. "ɪz ðə hɔɹn aʊt ðəɹ sʌmwɛɹ? ɪn ən aʊtbɪldɪŋ? dɪd jə si ðə dæɡɝ?"

Loial joined them, and they went back toward the manor, to be met at the small door by Mat, who opened it just as Rand reached for the handle. "Verin says you're not to do anything. If Hurin's found where the Horn is kept, then she says that's all we can do, now. She says we'll leave as soon as you come back, and make a plan. And I say this is the last time I go running back and forth with messages. If you want to say something to somebody, you can talk to them yourself from now on." Mat peered past them into the darkness. "Is the Horn out there somewhere? In an outbuilding? Did you see the dagger?"

ɹænd tɝn ɪm ɝaʊn ən ɡɑɾ ɪm bæk ɪnsaɪd. "ɪɾ ɪzən ɪn ən aʊtbɪldɪŋ, mæt. aɪ hoʊp vɛɹɪn əz ə ɡʊɾ aɪdiə ʌv wʌt tə də naʊ; aɪ doʊn əv ɛni."

Rand turned him around and got him back inside. "It isn't in an outbuilding, Mat. I hope Verin has a good idea of what to do now; I don't have any."

mæt lʊkt əz ɪf i wɑntəd tə æsk kwɛstʃənz, bʌɾ i lɛt hɪmsɛlf bi pʊʃt əlɔŋ ðə dɪmli lɪt kɔɹəɾɝ. hi ivən ɹɪmɛmbɝd tə lɪmp əz ðeɪ stɑɹɾəd əpstɛɹz.

Mat looked as if he wanted to ask questions, but he let himself be pushed along the dimly lit corridor. He even remembered to limp as they started upstairs.

wən ɹænd ən ði ʌðɝz ɹiɪntɝd ðə ɹumz fɪld wɪð noʊbəlz, ðeɪ ɹəsivd ə nʌmbɝ ə lʊks. ɹænd wʌndɝɾ ɪf ðeɪ sʌmhaʊ nu sʌmθɪŋ ʌv wʌt hæd hæpən aʊtsaɪd, əɹ ɪf i ʃʊɾə sɛn hʊɹɪn ən mæt tə ðə fɹʌn hɔl tə weɪt, bʌt ðən i ɹilaɪz ðə lʊks wɝ noʊ dɪfɹən fɹəm wʌt ðeɪ hæd bɪn bɪfɔɹ, kjʊɹiəs ən kælkjəleɪɾɪŋ, wʌndɝɪŋ wʌt ðə lɔɹɾ ən ði oʊɡiɝ hæd bɪn ʌp tə. sɝvəns wɝ ɪnvɪzəbəl tə ðiz pipəl. noʊ wʌn tʃɹaɪd tə əpɹoʊtʃ ðɛm, sɪns ðeɪ wɝ təɡɛðɝ. ɪt sim ðəɹ wɝ pɹoʊɾəkɔlz tə kənspɪɹəsi ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪt ɡeɪm; ɛniwʌn maɪt tʃɹaɪ tə lɪsən tə ə pɹaɪvət kɑnvɝseɪʃən, bʌt ðeɪ wəd nɑɾ ɪntʃɹuɾ ɑn ɪt.

When Rand and the others reentered the rooms filled with nobles, they received a number of looks. Rand wondered if they somehow knew something of what had happened outside, or if he should have sent Hurin and Mat to the front hall to wait, but then he realized the looks were no different from what they had been before, curious and calculating, wondering what the lord and the Ogier had been up to. Servants were invisible to these people. No one tried to approach them, since they were together. It seemed there were protocols to conspiracy in the Great Game; anyone might try to listen to a private conversation, but they would not intrude on it.

vɛɹɪn ən ɪŋtʃɹ wɝ stændɪŋ təɡɛðɝ, ən ðʌs ɔlsoʊ əloʊn. ɪŋtʃɹ lʊkt ə lɪɾəl deɪzd. vɛɹɪn ɡeɪv ɹænd ən ði ʌðɝ θɹi ə bɹif ɡlæns, fɹaʊn ət ðɛɹ ɪkspɹɛʃənz, ðən ɹisɛɾəld əɹ ʃɔl ən stɑɹɾəd fəɹ ði ɛntʃɹi hɔl.

Verin and Ingtar were standing together, and thus also alone. Ingtar looked a little dazed. Verin gave Rand and the other three a brief glance, frowned at their expressions, then resettled her shawl and started for the entry hall.

əz ðeɪ ɹitʃt ɪt, bɑɹθeɪnz əpɪɹɾ əz ɪf sʌmwʌn hæd toʊld ɪm ðeɪ wɝ livɪŋ. "ju ɡoʊ soʊ sun? vɛɹɪn sədaɪ, kən aɪ nɑɾ ɛntʃɹit jə tə steɪ lɔŋɡɝ?"

As they reached it, Barthanes appeared as if someone had told him they were leaving. "You go so soon? Verin Sedai, can I not entreat you to stay longer?"

vɛɹɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "wi mʌst ɡoʊ, lɔɹd bɑɹθeɪnz. aɪv nɑt bɪn ɪn kɛɹhin ɪn səm jɪɹz. aɪ wɑz ɡlæɾ ə jəɹ ɪnvɪteɪʃən tə jʌŋ ɹænd. ɪts bɪn . . . ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ."

Verin shook her head. "We must go, Lord Barthanes. I've not been in Cairhien in some years. I was glad of your invitation to young Rand. It has been . . . interesting."

"ðɛn ɡɹeɪs si jə seɪfli tə jəɹ ɪn. ðə ɡɹeɪt tʃɹi, ɪz ɪt nɑt? pɝhæps jəl feɪvɝ mi wɪð jəɹ pɹɛzəns əɡɛn? jə wəɾ ɑnɝ mi, vɛɹɪn sədaɪ, ən ju, lɔɹd ɹænd, ən ju, lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹ, nɑt tə mɛnʃən ju, lɔɪəl, sʌn ʌv ɑɹən sʌn ə hɑlən." hɪz baʊ wɑz ə lɪɾəl dipɝ fəɹ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ðən fəɹ ði ʌðɝz, bʌt stɪl noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə slaɪɾ ɪnkləneɪʃən.

"Then Grace see you safely to your inn. The Great Tree, is it not? Perhaps you will favor me with your presence again? You would honor me, Verin Sedai, and you, Lord Rand, and you, Lord Ingtar, not to mention you, Loial, son of Arent son of Halan." His bow was a little deeper for the Aes Sedai than for the others, but still no more than a slight inclination.

vɛɹɪn nɑɾəd ɪn æknɑlɪdʒmənt. "pɝhæps. ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin ju, lɔɹd bɑɹθeɪnz." ʃi tɝn fəɹ ðə dɔɹz.

Verin nodded in acknowledgment. "Perhaps. The Light illumine you, Lord Barthanes." She turned for the doors.

əz ɹænd muv tə fɑloʊ ði ʌðɝz, bɑɹθeɪnz kɑɾ ɪz sliv wɪð tu fɪŋɡɝz, hoʊldɪŋ ɪm bæk. mæt lʊkt əz ɪf i maɪt steɪ, tu, əntɪl hʊɹɪn pʊld ɪm tə dʒɔɪn vɛɹɪn ən ðə ɹɛst.

As Rand moved to follow the others, Barthanes caught his sleeve with two fingers, holding him back. Mat looked as if he might stay, too, until Hurin pulled him to join Verin and the rest.

"ju weɪɾ ivən dipɝ ɪn ðə ɡeɪm ðən aɪ θɔt," bɑɹθeɪnz sɛd sɔfli. "wɛn aɪ hɝd jəɹ neɪm, aɪ kəd nɑt bɪliv ɪt, jɛt jə keɪm, ən jə fɪt ðə dɪskɹɪpʃən, ænd. . . . aɪ wɑz ɡɪvən ə mɛsədʒ fəɹ ju. aɪ θɪŋk əl dɪlɪvɝ ɪɾ æftɝ ɔl."

"You wade even deeper in the Game than I thought," Barthanes said softly. "When I heard your name, I could not believe it, yet you came, and you fit the description, and. . . . I was given a message for you. I think I will deliver it after all."

ɹænd hæd fɛlt ə pɹɪklɪŋ əlɔŋ ɪz bækboʊn əz bɑɹθeɪnz spoʊk, bʌɾ ət ðə læst, hi stɛɹd. "ə mɛsədʒ? fɹəm hum? leɪɾi səlin?"

Rand had felt a prickling along his backbone as Barthanes spoke, but at the last, he stared. "A message? From whom? Lady Selene?"

"ə mæn. nɑt ðə sɔɹt fəɹ hum aɪ wəd juʒəwəli kæɹi mɛsədʒəz, bʌt hiz . . . sɝɾən . . . kleɪmz ɑn mi ðəɾ aɪ kænɑɾ ɪɡnɔɹ. hi ɡeɪv noʊ neɪm, bʌɾ i wɑz ə luɡɑɝɾɝ. ɑ! jə noʊ hɪm."

"A man. Not the sort for whom I would usually carry messages, but he has . . . certain . . . claims on me that I cannot ignore. He gave no name, but he was a Lugarder. Aaah! You know him."

"aɪ noʊ hɪm." feɪn lɛft ə mɛsədʒ? ɹænd lʊkt ɝaʊn ðə waɪd hɔl. mæt ən vɛɹɪn ən ði ʌðɝz wɝ weɪɾɪŋ baɪ ðə dɔɹz. lɪvɹid sɝvəns stʊd stɪfli əlɔŋ ðə wɔlz, ɹɛɾi tə lip əɾ ə kəmæn jɛɾ əpɪɹɪŋ niðɝ tə hɪɹ nɔɹ si. ðə saʊnz ə ðə ɡæðɝɪŋ floʊɾəd fɹəm dipɝ ɪn ðə mænɝ. ɪt dɪd nɑt lʊk laɪk ə pleɪs wɛɹ dɑɹkfɹɛnz maɪɾ ətæk. "wʌt mɛsədʒ?"

"I know him." Fain left a message? Rand looked around the wide hall. Mat and Verin and the others were waiting by the doors. Liveried servants stood stiffly along the walls, ready to leap at a command yet appearing neither to hear nor see. The sounds of the gathering floated from deeper in the manor. It did not look like a place where Darkfriends might attack. "What message?"

"hi sɛz hɪl weɪt fəɹ jə ɑn toʊmən hɛd. hiz wʌt jə sik, ən ɪf jə wɑn ɪt, jə mʌs fɑloʊ. ɪf jə ɹəfjuz tə fɑloʊ hɪm, hi sɛz hɪl haʊn jəɹ blʌd, ən jəɹ pipəl, ən ðoʊz jə lʌv əntɪl jəl feɪs hɪm. ɪt saʊnz mæd, ʌv kɔɹs, ə mæn laɪk ðət seɪɪŋ hɪl haʊn ə lɔɹd, ən jɛt, ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt hɪm. aɪ θɪŋk hiz mæd - hi ivən dɪnaɪd jə ɑɹ ə lɔɹd, əz ɛni aɪ kən pleɪnli si - bʌt ðəɹ ɪz stɪl sʌmθɪŋ. wʌɾ ɪz ɪɾ i kæɹiz wɪð hɪm, wɪð tʃɹɑləks tə ɡɑɹɾ ɪt? wʌɾ ɪz ɪt jə sik?" bɑɹθeɪnz simd ʃɑkt ət ðə dɝɛknəs ə hɪz oʊn kwɛstʃənz.

"He says he will wait for you on Toman Head. He has what you seek, and if you want it, you must follow. If you refuse to follow him, he says he will hound your blood, and your people, and those you love until you will face him. It sounds mad, of course, a man like that saying he will hound a lord, and yet, there was something about him. I think he is mad - he even denied you are a lord, as any eye can plainly see - but there is still something. What is it he carries with him, with Trollocs to guard it? What is it you seek?" Barthanes seemed shocked at the directness of his own questions.

"ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin ju, lɔɹd bɑɹθeɪnz." ɹænd mænədʒd ə baʊ, bʌɾ ɪz lɛɡz wɑbəld əz i dʒɔɪn vɛɹɪn ən ði ʌðɝz. hi wɑns mi tə fɑloʊ? ən hɪl hɝɾ ɛmənz fild, tæm, ɪf aɪ doʊnt. hi hæd noʊ daʊt feɪn kəd də ɪt, wəd də ɪt. ət list ɛɡwin ɪz seɪf, ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ. hi hæd sɪkənɪŋ ɪmədʒəz ə tʃɹɑləks dɪsɛndɪŋ ɪn hɔɹdz ɑn ɛmənz fild, ʌv aɪləs feɪdz stɔkɪŋ ɛɡwin. bʌt haʊ kən aɪ fɑloʊ hɪm? haʊ?

"The Light illumine you, Lord Barthanes." Rand managed a bow, but his legs wobbled as he joined Verin and the others. He wants me to follow? And he'll hurt Emond's Field, Tam, if I don't. He had no doubt Fain could do it, would do it. At least Egwene is safe, in the White Tower. He had sickening images of Trollocs descending in hordes on Emond's Field, of eyeless Fades stalking Egwene. But how can I follow him? How?

ðən i wɑz aʊɾ ɪn ðə naɪt, maʊntɪŋ ɹɛd. vɛɹɪn ən ɪŋtʃɹ ən ði ʌðɝz wɝ ɔl ɔlɹɛɾi ɑn ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz, ən ði ɛskɔɹɾ ə ʃaɪnɝənz wɑz kloʊzɪŋ ɹaʊn ðɛm.

Then he was out in the night, mounting Red. Verin and Ingtar and the others were all already on their horses, and the escort of Shienarans was closing round them.

"wʌt dɪd jə faɪnd?" vɛɹɪn dɪmændəd. "wɛɹ dʌz i kip ɪt?" hʊɹɪn klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊt laʊdli, ən lɔɪəl ʃɪftəɾ ɪn ɪz haɪ sæɾəl. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ pɪɹɾ ət ðɛm.

"What did you find?" Verin demanded. "Where does he keep it?" Hurin cleared his throat loudly, and Loial shifted in his high saddle. The Aes Sedai peered at them.

"feɪn əz teɪkən ðə hɔɹn tə toʊmən hɛd θɹu ə weɪɡeɪt," ɹænd sɛd dʌli. "baɪ ðɪs taɪm, hiz pɹɑbli ɔlɹɛɾi weɪɾɪŋ ðəɹ fəɹ mi."

"Fain has taken the Horn to Toman Head through a Waygate," Rand said dully. "By this time, he's probably already waiting there for me."

"wi wɪl spik ə ðɪs leɪɾɝ," vɛɹɪn sɛd, soʊ fɝmli ðət noʊ wʌn spoʊk əɾ ɔl ɑn ðə ɹaɪd bæk tə ðə sɪɾi, tə ðə ɡɹeɪt tʃɹi.

"We will speak of this later," Verin said, so firmly that no one spoke at all on the ride back to the city, to The Great Tree.

ənoʊ lɛft əm ðɛɹ, æftɝ ə kwaɪət wɝd fɹəm ɪŋtʃɹ, teɪkɪŋ ðə soʊlʒɝz bæk tə ðɛɹ ɪn ɪn ðə fɔɹɡeɪt. hʊɹɪn tʊk wʌn lʊk ət vɛɹɪnz sɛt feɪs baɪ ðə laɪɾ ə ðə kɑmən ɹum, mʌɾɝd sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊɾ eɪl, ən skɝid tə ə teɪbəl ɪn ə kɔɹnɝ, əloʊn. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ bɹʌʃt əsaɪd ði ɪnkipɝz səlɪsəɾəs hoʊps ðət ʃi hæɾ ɛndʒɔɪd hɝsɛlf, ən saɪlənli lɛd ɹænd ən ðə ɹɛs tə ðə pɹaɪvət daɪnɪŋ ɹum.

Uno left them there, after a quiet word from Ingtar, taking the soldiers back to their inn in the Foregate. Hurin took one look at Verin's set face by the light of the common room, muttered something about ale, and scurried to a table in a corner, alone. The Aes Sedai brushed aside the innkeeper's solicitous hopes that she had enjoyed herself, and silently led Rand and the rest to the private dining room.

pɛɹɪn lʊkt ʌp fɹəm ðə tʃɹævəlz ə dʒaɪn fɑɹstʃɹaɪɾɝ wən ðeɪ wɔkt ɪn, ən fɹaʊnd wən i sɔ ðɛɹ feɪsəz. "ɪt dɪdnt ɡoʊ wɛl, dɪɾ ɪt?" hi sɛd, kloʊzɪŋ ðə lɛðɝbaʊn bʊk. læmps ən biswæks kændəlz ɝaʊn ðə ɹum ɡeɪv ə ɡʊd laɪt; mɪstʃɹəs tidʒɹə tʃɑɹdʒ hɛvəli, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt stɪnt.

Perrin looked up from The Travels of Jain Farstrider when they walked in, and frowned when he saw their faces. "It didn't go well, did it?" he said, closing the leatherbound book. Lamps and beeswax candles around the room gave a good light; Mistress Tiedra charged heavily, but she did not stint.

vɛɹɪn kɛɹfəli foʊldəɾ əɹ ʃɔl ən leɪɾ ɪɾ əkɹɔs ðə bæk ʌv ə tʃɛɹ. "tɛl mi əɡɛn. ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz tʊk ðə hɔɹn θɹu ə weɪɡeɪt? ət bɑɹθeɪnzəz mænɝ?"

Verin carefully folded her shawl and laid it across the back of a chair. "Tell me again. The Darkfriends took the Horn through a Waygate? At Barthanes's manor?"

"ðə ɡɹaʊn ʌndɝ ðə mænɝ juz tə bi ən oʊɡiɝ ɡɹoʊv," lɔɪəl ɪkspleɪnd. "wɛn wi bɪlt. . . ." hɪz vɔɪs tʃɹeɪld ɔf ən ɪz ɪɹz wɪltɪɾ ʌndɝ əɹ lʊk.

"The ground under the manor used to be an Ogier grove," Loial explained. "When we built. . . ." His voice trailed off and his ears wilted under her look.

"hʊɹɪn fɑloʊɾ əm ɹaɪt tə ɪt." ɹænd wɛɹəli θɹu hɪmsɛlf ɪndə ə tʃɛɹ. aɪ hæv tə fɑloʊ mɔɹ ðən ɛvɝ, naʊ. bʌt haʊ? "aɪ oʊpən ɪt tə ʃoʊ hɪm i kəd stɪl fɑloʊ ðə tʃɹeɪl wɛɹɛvɝ ðeɪ wɛnt, ən ðə blæk wɪnd wɑz ðɛɹ. ɪt tʃɹaɪd tə ɹitʃ ʌs, bʌt lɔɪəl mænədʒ tə kloʊz ðə ɡeɪts bɪfɔɹ ɪt kəd kʌm ɔl ðə weɪ aʊt." hi kʌlɝɾ ə lɪɾəl ət ðæt, bʌt lɔɪəl hæd kloʊz ðə ɡeɪts, ən fəɹ ɔl i nu mætʃɪn ʃɪn maɪɾ əv meɪɾ ɪɾ aʊt wɪθaʊt ðæt. "ɪt wɑz stændɪŋ ɡɑɹd."

"Hurin followed them right to it." Rand wearily threw himself into a chair. I have to follow more than ever, now. But how? "I opened it to show him he could still follow the trail wherever they went, and the Black Wind was there. It tried to reach us, but Loial managed to close the gates before it could come all the way out." He colored a little at that, but Loial had closed the gates, and for all he knew Machin Shin might have made it out without that. "It was standing guard."

"ðə blæk wɪnd," mæt bɹiðd, fɹoʊzən hæfweɪ ɪndə ə tʃɛɹ. pɛɹɪn wɑz stɛɹɪŋ ət ɹænd, tu. soʊ wɝ vɛɹɪn ən ɪŋtʃɹ. mæt dʒɹɑpt ɪndə ðə tʃɛɹ wɪð ə θʌmp.

"The Black Wind," Mat breathed, frozen halfway into a chair. Perrin was staring at Rand, too. So were Verin and Ingtar. Mat dropped into the chair with a thump.

"ju mʌs bi mɪsteɪkən," vɛɹɪn sɛɾ ət læst. "mætʃɪn ʃɪn kəd nɑt bi juzd əz ə ɡɑɹd. noʊ wʌn kən kənstʃɹeɪn ðə blæk wɪn tə də ɛniθɪŋ."

"You must be mistaken," Verin said at last. "Machin Shin could not be used as a guard. No one can constrain the Black Wind to do anything."

"ɪts ə kɹitʃɝ ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn," mæt sɛd nʌmbli. "ðeɪɹ dɑɹkfɹɛnz. meɪbi ðeɪ nu haʊ tə æsk ɪt fəɹ hɛlp, əɹ meɪk ɪt hɛlp."

"It's a creature of the Dark One," Mat said numbly. "They're Darkfriends. Maybe they knew how to ask it for help, or make it help."

"noʊ wʌn noʊz ɪɡzækli wʌt mætʃɪn ʃɪn ɪz," vɛɹɪn sɛd, "ənlɛs, pɝhæps, ɪts ði ɛsəns ə mædnəs ən kɹulti. ɪt kænɑt bi ɹizənd wɪð, mæt, əɹ bɑɹɡənd wɪð, əɹ tɔk tə. ɪt kænɑɾ ivən bi fɔɹst, nɑt baɪ ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ lɪvɪŋ tədeɪ, ən pɝhæps nɑt baɪ ɛni hu ɛvɝ lɪvd. dʒju ɹɪli θɪŋk pdən feɪn kəd də wʌt tɛn ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd nɑt?" mæt ʃʊk ɪz hɛd.

"No one knows exactly what Machin Shin is," Verin said, "unless, perhaps, it is the essence of madness and cruelty. It cannot be reasoned with, Mat, or bargained with, or talked to. It cannot even be forced, not by any Aes Sedai living today, and perhaps not by any who ever lived. Do you really think Padan Fain could do what ten Aes Sedai could not?" Mat shook his head.

ðəɹ wɑz ən ɛɹ ə dɪspɛɹ ɪn ðə ɹum, ʌv hoʊp ən pɝpəs lɔst. ðə ɡoʊl ðeɪ hæd sɔt hæd vænɪʃt, ən ivən vɛɹɪnz feɪs wɔɹ ə flaʊndɝɪŋ ɪkspɹɛʃən.

There was an air of despair in the room, of hope and purpose lost. The goal they had sought had vanished, and even Verin's face wore a floundering expression.

"aɪd nɛvɝ əv θɔt feɪn hæd ðə kɝədʒ fəɹ ðə weɪz." ɪŋtʃɹ saʊndəɾ ɔlmoʊs maɪld, bʌt sʌɾənli hi bæŋd ɪz fɪst əɡɛns ðə wɔl. "aɪ də nɑt kɛɹ haʊ, əɹ ivən ɪf, mætʃɪn ʃɪn wɝks ɑn feɪnz bɪhæf. ðeɪv teɪkən ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ ɪndə ðə weɪz, ɛɛs sədaɪ. baɪ naʊ ðeɪ kəd bi ɪn ðə blaɪt, əɹ hæfweɪ tə tɛɹ əɹ tæntʃəkoʊ, əɹ ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ði il weɪst. ðə hɔɹn ɪz lɔst. aɪm lɔst." hɪz hænz dʒɹɑp tə hɪz saɪdz, ən ɪz ʃoʊldɝz slʌmpt. "aɪ æm lɔst."

"I'd never have thought Fain had the courage for the Ways." Ingtar sounded almost mild, but suddenly he banged his fist against the wall. "I do not care how, or even if, Machin Shin works on Fain's behalf. They have taken the Horn of Valere into the Ways, Aes Sedai. By now they could be in the Blight, or halfway to Tear or Tanchico, or the other side of the Aiel Waste. The Horn is lost. I am lost." His hands dropped to his sides, and his shoulders slumped. "I am lost."

"feɪn ɪz teɪkɪŋ ɪt tə toʊmən hɛd," ɹænd sɛd, ən wɑz ɪmiɾiətli ði əbdʒɛkt ʌv ɔl aɪz əɡɛn.

"Fain is taking it to Toman Head," Rand said, and was immediately the object of all eyes again.

vɛɹɪn stʌɾid ɪm nɛɹoʊli. "ju sɛd ðət bɪfɔɹ. haʊ dʒju noʊ?"

Verin studied him narrowly. "You said that before. How do you know?"

"hi lɛft ə mɛsədʒ wɪð bɑɹθeɪnz," ɹænd sɛd.

"He left a message with Barthanes," Rand said.

"ə tʃɹɪk," ɪŋtʃɹ snɪɹd. "hid nɑt tɛl əs wɛɹ tə fɑloʊ."

"A trick," Ingtar sneered. "He'd not tell us where to follow."

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt ðə ɹɛst ə jə ɑɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə du," ɹænd sɛd, "bʌɾ aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ tə toʊmən hɛd. aɪ hæv tə. aɪ liv ət fɝs laɪt."

"I don't know what the rest of you are going to do," Rand said, "but I am going to Toman Head. I have to. I leave at first light."

"bʌt, ɹænd," lɔɪəl sɛd, "ɪt wɪl teɪk əs mʌnθs tə ɹitʃ toʊmən hɛd. wʌt meɪks jə θɪŋk feɪn wɪl weɪt ðəɹ fəɹ ʌs?"

"But, Rand," Loial said, "it will take us months to reach Toman Head. What makes you think Fain will wait there for us?"

"hi wɪl weɪt." bʌt haʊ lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ i dɪsaɪdz aɪm nɑt kʌmɪŋ? waɪ dɪɾ i sɛt ðət ɡɑɹɾ ɪf i wɑns mi tə fɑloʊ? "lɔɪəl, aɪ min tə ɹaɪɾ əz hɑɹɾ əz aɪ kæn, ən ɪf aɪ ɹaɪd ɹɛd tə dɛθ, əl baɪ ənʌðɝ hɔɹs, əɹ stil ənʌðɝ, ɪf aɪ hæv tə. ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ jə wɑnə kʌm?"

"He will wait." But how long before he decides I'm not coming? Why did he set that guard if he wants me to follow? "Loial, I mean to ride as hard as I can, and if I ride Red to death, I'll buy another horse, or steal another, if I have to. Are you sure you want to come?"

"aɪv steɪd wɪð jə ðɪs lɔŋ, ɹænd. waɪ wəɾ aɪ stɑp naʊ?" lɔɪəl pʊld aʊɾ ɪz paɪp ən paʊtʃ ən bɪɡæn θʌmɪŋ təbæk ɪndə ðə bɪɡ boʊl. "ju si, aɪ laɪk ju. aɪ wəd laɪk jə ivən ɪf jə wɝn tɑvɝən. meɪbi aɪ laɪk jə dɪspaɪɾ ɪt. jə də sim tə ɡɛt mi nɛk-dip ɪn hɑt wɔɾɝ. ɪn ɛni keɪs, aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ wɪð ju." hi sʌkt ɑn ðə paɪpɛstəm tə tɛs ðə dʒɹɔ, ðən tʊk ə splɪntɝ fɹəm ðə stoʊn dʒɑɹ ɑn ðə mæntəl ən θɹʌst ɪɾ ɪndə ə kændəl fleɪm fəɹ ə laɪt. "æn aɪ doʊn θɪŋk jə kən ɹɪli stɑp mi."

"I've stayed with you this long, Rand. Why would I stop now?" Loial pulled out his pipe and pouch and began thumbing tabac into the big bowl. "You see, I like you. I would like you even if you weren't ta'veren. Maybe I like you despite it. You do seem to get me neck-deep in hot water. In any case, I am going with you." He sucked on the pipestem to test the draw, then took a splinter from the stone jar on the mantel and thrust it into a candle flame for a light. "And I don't think you can really stop me."

"wɛl, ɪm ɡoʊɪŋ," mæt sɛd. "feɪn stɪl əz ðət dæɡɝ, soʊ aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ. bʌɾ ɔl ðət sɝvən bɪznəs ɛndəd tənaɪt."

"Well, I'm going," Mat said. "Fain still has that dagger, so I'm going. But all that servant business ended tonight."

pɛɹɪn saɪd, ən ɪntʃɹəspɛktɪv lʊk ɪn ɪz jɛloʊ aɪz. "aɪ səpoʊz əl kʌm əlɔŋ, tu." æftɝ ə moʊmənt, hi ɡɹɪnd. "sʌmbɑɾi hæz tə kip mæt aʊɾ ə tʃɹʌbəl."

Perrin sighed, an introspective look in his yellow eyes. "I suppose I'll come along, too." After a moment, he grinned. "Somebody has to keep Mat out of trouble."

"nɑɾ ivən ə klɛvɝ tʃɹɪk," ɪŋtʃɹ mʌɾɝd. "sʌmhaʊ, əl ɡɛt bɑɹθeɪnz əloʊn, ən əl lɝn ðə tʃɹuθ. aɪ min tə hæv ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ, nɑt tʃeɪs dʒæk oʊ' ðə wɪsps."

"Not even a clever trick," Ingtar muttered. "Somehow, I'll get Barthanes alone, and I will learn the truth. I mean to have the Horn of Valere, not chase Jak o' the Wisps."

"ɪt meɪ nɑt bi ə tʃɹɪk," vɛɹɪn sɛd kɛɹfəli, simɪŋ tə stʌɾi ðə flɔɹ ʌndɝ əɹ toʊz. "ðɛɹ wɝ sɝɾən θɪŋz lɛft ɪn ðə dʌnʒənz ət fæl dæɹə, ɹaɪɾɪŋz ðəɾ ɪndəkeɪɾəd ə kənɛkʃən bɪtwin wʌt hæpən ðət naɪɾ ænd" - ʃi ɡeɪv ɹænd ə kwɪk ɡlæns ʌndɝ loʊɝd bɹaʊz - "toʊmən hɛd. aɪ stɪl də nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn əm kəmplitli, bʌɾ aɪ bɪliv wi mʌst ɡoʊ tə toʊmən hɛd. ən aɪ bɪliv wɪl faɪn ðə hɔɹn ðɛɹ."

"It may not be a trick," Verin said carefully, seeming to study the floor under her toes. "There were certain things left in the dungeons at Fal Dara, writings that indicated a connection between what happened that night and" - she gave Rand a quick glance under lowered brows - "Toman Head. I still do not understand them completely, but I believe we must go to Toman Head. And I believe we will find the Horn there."

"ivən ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə toʊmən hɛd," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd, "baɪ ðə taɪm wi ɹitʃ ɪt, feɪn əɹ wʌn ə ði ʌðɝ dɑɹkfɹɛnz cʊɾə bloʊn ðə hɔɹn ə hʌnʒɹəd taɪmz, ən ðə hɪɹoʊz ɹɪtɝn fɹəm ðə ɡɹeɪv wɪl ɹaɪd fəɹ ðə ʃædoʊ."

"Even if they are going to Toman Head," Ingtar said, "by the time we reach it, Fain or one of the other Darkfriends could have blown the Horn a hundred times, and the heroes returned from the grave will ride for the Shadow."

"feɪn cʊɾə bloʊn ðə hɔɹn ə hʌnʒɹəd taɪmz sɪns livɪŋ fæl dæɹə," vɛɹɪn toʊl hɪm. "æn aɪ θɪŋk i wəd hæv, ɪf i kəɾ oʊpən ðə tʃɛst. wʌt wi mʌst wɝi əbaʊɾ ɪz ðəɾ i maɪt faɪn sʌmwʌn u dʌz noʊ haʊ tə oʊpən ɪt. wi mʌs fɑloʊ hɪm əlɔŋ ðə weɪz."

"Fain could have blown the Horn a hundred times since leaving Fal Dara," Verin told him. "And I think he would have, if he could open the chest. What we must worry about is that he might find someone who does know how to open it. We must follow him along the Ways."

pɛɹɪnz hɛd keɪm ʌp ʃɑɹpli, ən mæt ʃɪftəɾ ɪn ɪz tʃɛɹ. lɔɪəl ɡeɪv ə loʊ moʊn.

Perrin's head came up sharply, and Mat shifted in his chair. Loial gave a low moan.

"ivən ɪf wi kəd sʌmhaʊ snik pæs bɑɹθeɪnzəz ɡɑɹdz," ɹænd sɛd, "aɪ θɪŋk wɪl faɪn mætʃɪn ʃɪn stɪl ðɛɹ. wi kænɑt juz ðə weɪz."

"Even if we could somehow sneak past Barthanes's guards," Rand said, "I think we'll find Machin Shin still there. We cannot use the Ways."

"haʊ mɛni ʌv əs kəd snik ɑntu bɑɹθeɪnzəz ɡɹaʊnz?" vɛɹɪn sɛd dɪsmɪsɪvli. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ ʌðɝ weɪɡeɪts. stɛɾɪŋ tsəfu laɪz nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm ðə sɪɾi, saʊθ ən ist. ɪts ə jʌŋ stɛɾɪŋ, ɹiɾɪskʌvɝd oʊnli pɝhæps sɪks hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz əɡoʊ, bʌt ði oʊɡiɝ ɛldɝz wɝ stɪl ɡɹoʊɪŋ ðə weɪz, ðɛn. stɛɾɪŋ tsəfu wɪl əv ə weɪɡeɪt. ɪts ðəɹ ən wɪl ɹaɪɾ ət fɝs laɪt."

"How many of us could sneak onto Barthanes's grounds?" Verin said dismissively. "There are other Waygates. Stedding Tsofu lies not far from the city, south and east. It is a young stedding, rediscovered only perhaps six hundred years ago, but the Ogier Elders were still growing the Ways, then. Stedding Tsofu will have a Waygate. It is there and we will ride at first light."

lɔɪəl meɪɾ ə slaɪtli laʊɾɝ saʊnd, ən ɹænd wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ wɛðɝ ɪt ɹəfɝd tə ðə weɪɡeɪɾ əɹ ðə stɛɾɪŋ.

Loial made a slightly louder sound, and Rand was not sure whether it referred to the Waygate or the stedding.

ɪŋtʃɹ stɪl dɪd nɑt sim kənvɪnst, bʌt vɛɹɪn wɑz əz smuð ən əz ɪmplækəbəl əz snoʊ slaɪɾɪŋ daʊn ə maʊntənsaɪd. "ju wɪl əv jəɹ soʊlʒɝz ɹɛɾi tə ɹaɪd, ɪŋtʃɹ. sɛn hʊɹɪn tə tɛl ənoʊ bɪfɔɹ i ɡoʊz tə bɛd. aɪ θɪŋk wi ʃəɾ ɔl ɡoʊ tə bɛɾ əz sun əz pɑsəbəl. ðiz dɑɹkfɹɛnz əv ɡeɪn ət list ə deɪ ɑn əs ɔlɹɛɾi, ən aɪ min tə meɪk ʌp əz mʌtʃ ʌv ɪɾ əz aɪ kən təmɑɹoʊ." soʊ fɝm wɑz ðə plʌmp ɛɛs sədaɪz mænɝ ðət ʃi wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi hɝɾɪŋ ɪŋtʃɹ tə ðə dɔɹ bɪfɔɹ ʃi fɪnɪʃt spikɪŋ.

Ingtar still did not seem convinced, but Verin was as smooth and as implacable as snow sliding down a mountainside. "You will have your soldiers ready to ride, Ingtar. Send Hurin to tell Uno before he goes to bed. I think we should all go to bed as soon as possible. These Darkfriends have gained at least a day on us already, and I mean to make up as much of it as I can tomorrow." So firm was the plump Aes Sedai's manner that she was already herding Ingtar to the door before she finished speaking.

ɹænd fɑloʊd ði ʌðɝz aʊt, bʌɾ ət ðə dɔɹ i stɑp bɪsaɪd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən wɑtʃt mæt hɛɾɪŋ daʊn ðə kændəl-lɪt hɔl. "waɪ dʌz i lʊk laɪk ðæt?" hi æsk hɝ. "aɪ θɔt jə hil hɪm, ɪnʌf tə ɡɪv ɪm səm taɪm, ɛniweɪ."

Rand followed the others out, but at the door he stopped beside the Aes Sedai and watched Mat heading down the candle-lit hall. "Why does he look like that?" he asked her. "I thought you Healed him, enough to give him some time, anyway."

ʃi weɪɾəd əntɪl mæt ən ði ʌðɝz hæd tɝn ʌp ðə stɛɹz bɪfɔɹ spikɪŋ. "əpɛɹənli, ɪt dɪd nɑt wɝk soʊ wɛl əz wi bɪlivd. ðə sɪknəs teɪks ən ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ kɔɹs ɪn hɪm. hɪz stʃɹɛŋkθ ɹɪmeɪnz; hɪl kip ðət tə ði ɛnd, aɪ θɪŋk. bʌɾ ɪz bɑɾi weɪsts əweɪ. ənʌðɝ fju wiks, ət moʊst, aɪ wəd seɪ. jə si, ðəɹ ɪz ɹizən fəɹ heɪst."

She waited until Mat and the others had turned up the stairs before speaking. "Apparently, it did not work so well as we believed. The sickness takes an interesting course in him. His strength remains; he will keep that to the end, I think. But his body wastes away. Another few weeks, at most, I would say. You see, there is reason for haste."

"aɪ də nɑt niɾ ənʌðɝ spɝ, ɛɛs sədaɪ," ɹænd sɛd, meɪkɪŋ ðə taɪɾəl saʊn hɑɹd. mæt. ðə hɔɹn. feɪnz θɹɛt. laɪt, ɛɡwin! bɝn mi, aɪ doʊnt niɾ ənʌðɝ spɝ.

"I do not need another spur, Aes Sedai," Rand said, making the title sound hard. Mat. The Horn. Fain's threat. Light, Egwene! Burn me, I don't need another spur.

"ænd wʌɾ ə ju, ɹænd ælθɹ? dʒju fil wɛl? dʒju faɪɾ ɪt stɪl, əɹ əv jə jɛt sɝɛndɝd tə ðə wil?"

"And what of you, Rand al'Thor? Do you feel well? Do you fight it still, or have you yet surrendered to the Wheel?"

"aɪ ɹaɪd wɪð jə tə faɪn ðə hɔɹn," hi toʊl hɝ. "bɪɑn ðæt, ðəɹ ɪz nʌθɪŋ bɪtwin mi ən ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ. dʒju ʌndɝstæn mi? nʌθɪŋ!"

"I ride with you to find the Horn," he told her. "Beyond that, there is nothing between me and any Aes Sedai. Do you understand me? Nothing!"

ʃi dɪd nɑt spik, ən i wɔkt əweɪ fɹəm hɝ, bʌt wən i tɝn tə teɪk ðə stɛɹz ʃi wɑz stɪl wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm, dɑɹk aɪz ʃɑɹp ən kənsɪɾɝɪŋ.

She did not speak, and he walked away from her, but when he turned to take the stairs she was still watching him, dark eyes sharp and considering.


tʃæptɝ θɝɾifɔɹ


CHAPTER 34

ðə wil wivz


The Wheel Weaves

ðə fɝs laɪɾ ə mɔɹnɪŋ ɔlɹɛɾi pɝl ðə skaɪ baɪ ðə taɪm tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn faʊn hɪmsɛlf tʃɹʌdʒɪŋ bæk tə ðə bʌntʃ ʌv ɡɹeɪps. ivən wɛɹ ðə hɔlz ən tævɝnz leɪ θɪkəst, ðəɹ wɑz ə bɹif taɪm wən ðə fɔɹɡeɪt leɪ kwaɪət, ɡæðɝɪŋ ɪts bɹɛθ. ɪn ɪz pɹɛzən mud, tɑm wəd nɑɾ əv noʊɾəst ɪf ði ɛmpti stʃɹit hæd bɪn ɑn faɪɝ.

The first light of morning already pearled the sky by the time Thom Merrilin found himself trudging back to The Bunch of Grapes. Even where the halls and taverns lay thickest, there was a brief time when the Foregate lay quiet, gathering its breath. In his present mood, Thom would not have noticed if the empty street had been on fire.

səm ə bɑɹθeɪnzəz ɡɛsts hæɾ ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn kipɪŋ ɪm lɔŋ æftɝ moʊs hæd ɡɔn, lɔŋ æftɝ bɑɹθeɪnz hæd teɪkən hɪmsɛlf tə bɛd. ɪt hæd bɪn ɪz oʊn fɔl fəɹ livɪŋ ðə ɡɹeɪt hʌn ə ðə hɔɹn, tʃeɪnʒɪŋ tə ðə sɔɹɾ ə teɪlz i toʊld ən sɔŋz i sæŋ ɪn ðə vɪlədʒəz, "mɑɹə ən ðə θɹi fulɪʃ kɪŋz" ən haʊ susə teɪm dʒaɪn fɑɹstʃɹaɪɾɝ ən stɔɹiz ʌv ænlə ðə waɪz kaʊnsəlɝ. hi hæd mɛn ðə tʃɔɪsəz tə bi ə pɹaɪvət kɑmɛn ɑn ðɛɹ stupɪɾɪti, nɛvɝ dʒɹimɪŋ ɛni ʌv əm maɪt lɪsən, mʌtʃ lɛs bi ɪntʃɹiɡd. ɪntʃɹiɡd ɪn ə weɪ. ðeɪ hæd dɪmændəd mɔɹ ə ðə seɪm, bʌt ðeɪ hæd læft ɪn ðə ɹɔŋ pleɪsəz, ət ðə ɹɔŋ θɪŋz. ðeɪ hæd læft ət hɪm, tu, əpɛɹənli θɪŋkɪŋ i wəd nɑt noʊɾəs, əɹ ɛls ðəɾ ə fʊl pɝs stʌft ɪn ɪz pɑkət wəd hil ɛni wunz. hi hæɾ ɔlmoʊs θɹoʊn ɪɾ əweɪ twaɪs ɔlɹɛɾi.

Some of Barthanes's guests had insisted on keeping him long after most had gone, long after Barthanes had taken himself to bed. It had been his own fault for leaving The Great Hunt of the Horn, changing to the sort of tales he told and songs he sang in the villages, "Mara and the Three Foolish Kings" and How Susa Tamed Jain Farstrider and stories of Anla the Wise Councilor. He had meant the choices to be a private comment on their stupidity, never dreaming any of them might listen, much less be intrigued. Intrigued in a way. They had demanded more of the same, but they had laughed in the wrong places, at the wrong things. They had laughed at him, too, apparently thinking he would not notice, or else that a full purse stuffed in his pocket would heal any wounds. He had almost thrown it away twice already.

ðə hɛvi pɝs bɝnɪŋ ɪz pɑkəɾ ən pɹaɪd wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli ɹizən fəɹ ɪz mud, nɔɹ ivən ðə noʊbəlz' kəntɛmpt. ðeɪ hæɾ æskt kwɛstʃənz əbaʊt ɹænd, nɑɾ ivən bɑðɝɪŋ tə bi sʌɾəl wɪð ə mɪɹ ɡlimən. waɪ wɑz ɹænd ɪn kɛɹhin? waɪ hæɾ ən ændɔɝən lɔɹd teɪkən hɪm, ə ɡlimən, əsaɪd? tu mɛni kwɛstʃənz. hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ɪz ænsɝz hæd bɪn klɛvɝ ɪnʌf. hɪz ɹiflɛksəz fəɹ ðə ɡɹeɪt ɡeɪm wɝ ɹʌsti.

The heavy purse burning his pocket and pride was not the only reason for his mood, nor even the nobles' contempt. They had asked questions about Rand, not even bothering to be subtle with a mere gleeman. Why was Rand in Cairhien? Why had an Andoran lord taken him, a gleeman, aside? Too many questions. He was not sure his answers had been clever enough. His reflexes for the Great Game were rusty.

bɪfɔɹ tɝnɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə bʌntʃ ʌv ɡɹeɪps, hi hæd ɡɔn tə ðə ɡɹeɪt tʃɹi; ɪt wɑz nɑt dɪfəkəl tə faɪnd wɛɹ sʌmwʌn wɑz steɪɪŋ ɪn kɛɹhin, ɪf jə pɹɛst ə pɑm əɹ tu wɪð sɪlvɝ. hi wɑz stɪl nɑt ʃʊɹ wʌɾ i hæɾ ɪntɛndəd tə seɪ. ɹænd wɑz ɡɔn wɪð ɪz fɹɛnz, ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɪt lɛft ə filɪŋ ə sʌmθɪŋ nɑt dʌn. ðə bɔɪz ɑn ɪz oʊn, naʊ. bɝn mi, aɪm aʊɾ ʌv ɪt!

Before turning toward The Bunch of Grapes, he had gone to The Great Tree; it was not difficult to find where someone was staying in Cairhien, if you pressed a palm or two with silver. He was still not sure what he had intended to say. Rand was gone with his friends, and the Aes Sedai. It left a feeling of something not done. The boy's on his own, now. Burn me, I'm out of it!

hi stʃɹoʊd θɹu ðə kɑmən ɹum, ɛmpti əz ɪt sɛldəm wɑz, ən tʊk ðə stɛps tu əɾ ə taɪm. ət list, hi tʃɹaɪd tə; hɪz ɹaɪt lɛɡ dɪd nɑt bɛnd wɛl, ən i nɪɹli fɛl. mʌɾɝɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf, hi klaɪm ðə ɹɛst ə ðə weɪ əɾ ə sloʊɝ peɪs, ən oʊpən ðə dɔɹ tə hɪz ɹum sɔfli, soʊ əz nɑt tə weɪk dinə.

He strode through the common room, empty as it seldom was, and took the steps two at a time. At least, he tried to; his right leg did not bend well, and he nearly fell. Muttering to himself, he climbed the rest of the way at a slower pace, and opened the door to his room softly, so as not to wake Dena.

dɪspaɪt hɪmsɛlf, hi smaɪld wən i sɔ hɝ laɪɪŋ ɑn ðə bɛd wɪð əɹ feɪs tɝn tə ðə wɔl, stɪl ɪn əɹ dʒɹɛs. fɛl əslip weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ mi. ful ɡɝl. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ə kaɪnli θɔt; hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ðəɹ wɑz ɛniθɪŋ ʃi wəd də ðəɾ i wəd nɑt fɝɡɪv əɹ ɪkskjus. dəsaɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə spɝ ə ðə moʊmən ðət tənaɪt wɑz ðə naɪt hid lɛɾ əɹ pɝfɔɹm fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm, hi loʊɝɾ ɪz hɑɹp keɪs tə ðə flɔɹ ən pʊɾ ə hæn ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝ, tə weɪk əɹ ən tɛl hɝ.

Despite himself, he smiled when he saw her lying on the bed with her face turned to the wall, still in her dress. Fell asleep waiting for me. Fool girl. But it was a kindly thought; he was not sure there was anything she would do that he would not forgive or excuse. Deciding on the spur of the moment that tonight was the night he'd let her perform for the first time, he lowered his harp case to the floor and put a hand on her shoulder, to wake her and tell her.

ʃi ɹoʊld lɪmpli ɑntu hɝ bæk, stɛɹɪŋ ʌp ət hɪm, ɡleɪzd aɪz oʊpən waɪɾ əbʌv ðə ɡæʃ əkɹɔs əɹ θɹoʊt. ðə saɪɾ ə ðə bɛd ðət hæd bɪn hɪɾən baɪ hɝ bɑɾi wɑz dɑɹk ən sɑɾən.

She rolled limply onto her back, staring up at him, glazed eyes open wide above the gash across her throat. The side of the bed that had been hidden by her body was dark and sodden.

tɑmz stʌmək hivd; ɪf ɪz θɹoʊt hæd nɑt bɪn soʊ taɪɾ i kəd nɑt bɹið, hi wəɾ əv vɑməɾəd, əɹ skɹimd, əɹ boʊθ.

Thom's stomach heaved; if his throat had not been so tight he could not breathe, he would have vomited, or screamed, or both.

hi hæɾ oʊnli ðə kɹikɪŋ ʌv wɔɹdʒɹoʊb dɔɹz fəɹ wɔɹnɪŋ. hi spʌn, naɪvz kʌmɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɪz slivz ən livɪŋ ɪz hænz ɪn ðə seɪm moʊʃən. ðə fɝs bleɪd tʊk ðə θɹoʊɾ ʌv ə fæt, bɔldɪŋ mæn wɪð ə dæɡɝ ɪn ɪz hænd; ðə mæn stʌmbəl bæk, blʌd bʌbəlɪŋ ɝaʊn ɪz klʌtʃɪŋ fɪŋɡɝz əz i tʃɹaɪd tə kɹaɪ aʊt.

He had only the creaking of wardrobe doors for warning. He spun, knives coming out of his sleeves and leaving his hands in the same motion. The first blade took the throat of a fat, balding man with a dagger in his hand; the man stumbled back, blood bubbling around his clutching fingers as he tried to cry out.

spɪnɪŋ ɑn ɪz bæd lɛɡ θɹu tɑmz ʌðɝ bleɪɾ ɔf, ðoʊ; ðə naɪf stʌk ɪn ðə ɹaɪt ʃoʊldɝ ʌv ə hɛvəli mʌsəl mæn wɪð skɑɹz ɑn ɪz feɪs, hu wɑz klaɪmɪŋ aʊɾ ə ði ʌðɝ wɔɹdʒɹoʊb. ðə bɪɡ mænz naɪf dʒɹɑp fɹəm ə hæn ðət sʌɾənli wəd nɑt də wʌɾ i wɑntəd, ən i lʌmbɝd fəɹ ðə dɔɹ.

Spinning on his bad leg threw Thom's other blade off, though; the knife stuck in the right shoulder of a heavily muscled man with scars on his face, who was climbing out of the other wardrobe. The big man's knife dropped from a hand that suddenly would not do what he wanted, and he lumbered for the door.

bɪfɔɹ i kəd teɪk ə sɛkən stɛp, tɑm pɹədust ənʌðɝ naɪf ən slæʃt ɪm əkɹɔs ðə bæk ə hɪz lɛɡ. ðə bɪɡ mæn jɛld ən stʌmbəld, ən tɑm sizd ə hændfʊl ʌv ɡɹisi hɛɹ, slæmɪŋ ɪz feɪs əɡɛns ðə wɔl bɪsaɪd ðə dɔɹ; ðə mæn skɹimd əɡɛn əz ðə naɪf hɪl stɪkɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɪz ʃoʊldɝ hɪt ðə dɔɹ.

Before he could take a second step, Thom produced another knife and slashed him across the back of his leg. The big man yelled and stumbled, and Thom seized a handful of greasy hair, slamming his face against the wall beside the door; the man screamed again as the knife hilt sticking out of his shoulder hit the door.

tɑm θɹʌs ðə bleɪɾ ɪn ɪz hæn tə wɪðɪn ən ɪntʃ ə ðə mænz dɑɹk aɪ. ðə skɑɹz ɑn ðə bɪɡ mænz feɪs ɡeɪv ɪm ə hɑɹd lʊk, bʌɾ i stɛɹɾ ət ðə pɔɪnt wɪθaʊt blɪŋkɪŋ ən dɪd nɑt muv ə mʌsəl. ðə fæt mæn, laɪɪŋ hæf ɪn ðə wɔɹdʒɹoʊb, kɪkt ə læs kɪk ən wɑz stɪl.

Thom thrust the blade in his hand to within an inch of the man's dark eye. The scars on the big man's face gave him a hard look, but he stared at the point without blinking and did not move a muscle. The fat man, lying half in the wardrobe, kicked a last kick and was still.

"bɪfɔɹ aɪ kɪl ju," tɑm sɛd, "tɛl mi. waɪ?" hɪz vɔɪs wɑz kwaɪət, nʌm; hi fɛl nʌm ɪnsaɪd.

"Before I kill you," Thom said, "tell me. Why?" His voice was quiet, numb; he felt numb inside.

"ðə ɡɹeɪt ɡeɪm," ðə mæn sɛd kwɪkli. hɪz æksɛnt wɑz ə ðə stʃɹits, ən ɪz kloʊðz əz wɛl, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ ə ʃeɪd tu faɪn, tu ənwɹn; hi hæd mɔɹ kɔɪn tə spɛn ðən ɛni fɔɹɡeɪɾɝ ʃʊd. "nʌθɪŋ əɡɛns jə pɝsənəl, jə si? ɪts dʒʌs ðə ɡeɪm."

"The Great Game," the man said quickly. His accent was of the streets, and his clothes as well, but they were a shade too fine, too unworn; he had more coin to spend than any Foregater should. "Nothing against you personal, you see? It is just the Game."

"ðə ɡeɪm? aɪm nɑt mɪkst ʌp ɪn deɪz deɪmɑɹ! hu wəd wɑnə kɪl mi fəɹ ðə ɡɹeɪt ɡeɪm?" ðə mæn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. tɑm muvd ɪz bleɪd kloʊsɝ. ɪf ðə fɛloʊ blɪŋkt, hɪz aɪlæʃɪz wəd bɹʌʃ ðə pɔɪnt. "hu?"

"The Game? I'm not mixed up in Daes Dae'mar! Who would want to kill me for the Great Game?" The man hesitated. Thom moved his blade closer. If the fellow blinked, his eyelashes would brush the point. "Who?"

"bɑɹθeɪnz," keɪm ðə hɔɹs ænsɝ. "lɔɹd bɑɹθeɪnz. wi wəd nɑɾ əv kɪl ju. bɑɹθeɪnz wɑns ɪnfɝmeɪʃən. wi dʒʌst wɑntəd tə faɪn aʊt wʌt jə noʊ. ðəɹ kən bi ɡoʊld ɪn ɪt fəɹ ju. ə naɪs, fæt ɡoʊldən kɹaʊn fəɹ wʌt jə noʊ. meɪbi tu."

"Barthanes," came the hoarse answer. "Lord Barthanes. We would not have killed you. Barthanes wants information. We just wanted to find out what you know. There can be gold in it for you. A nice, fat golden crown for what you know. Maybe two."

"laɪɝ! aɪ wɑz ɪn bɑɹθeɪnzəz mænɝ læs naɪt, əz kloʊs tə hɪm əz aɪm tə ju. ɪf i wɑntəɾ ɛniθɪŋ ə mi, aɪd nɛvɝ əv lɛft əlaɪv."

"Liar! I was in Barthanes's manor last night, as close to him as I am to you. If he wanted anything of me, I'd never have left alive."

"aɪ tɛl ju, wɪv bɪn lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ju, əɹ ɛniwʌn u noʊz əbaʊt ðɪs ændɔɝən lɔɹd, fəɹ deɪz. aɪ nɛvɝ hɝd jəɹ neɪm əntɪl læs naɪt, daʊnstɛɹz. lɔɹd bɑɹθeɪnz ɪz dʒɛnɝəs. ɪt kəd bi faɪv kɹaʊnz."

"I tell you, we have been looking for you, or anyone who knows about this Andoran lord, for days. I never heard your name until last night, downstairs. Lord Barthanes is generous. It could be five crowns."

ðə mæn tʃɹaɪd tə pʊl ɪz hɛɾ əweɪ fɹəm ðə naɪf ɪn tɑmz hænd, ən tɑm pʊʃt ɪm hɑɹɾɝ əɡɛns ðə wɔl. "wʌɾ ændɔɝən lɔɹd?" bʌɾ i nu. ðə laɪt hɛlp hɪm, hi nu.

The man tried to pull his head away from the knife in Thom's hand, and Thom pushed him harder against the wall. "What Andoran lord?" But he knew. The Light help him, he knew.

"ɹænd. ʌv haʊs ælθɹ. tɔl. jʌŋ. ə bleɪdmæstɝ, əɹ ət list i wɛɹz ðə sɔɹd. aɪ noʊ hi keɪm tə si ju. hɪm ən ən oʊɡiɝ, ən jə tɔkt. tɛl mi wʌt jə noʊ. aɪ maɪɾ ivən θɹoʊ ɪn ə kɹaʊn əɹ tu, maɪsɛlf."

"Rand. Of House al'Thor. Tall. Young. A blademaster, or at least he wears the sword. I know he came to see you. Him and an Ogier, and you talked. Tell me what you know. I might even throw in a crown or two, myself."

"ju ful," tɑm bɹiðd. dinə daɪd fəɹ ðɪs? oʊ, laɪt, ʃiz dɛd. hi fɛlt əz ɪf i wɑntəd tə kɹaɪ. "ðə bɔɪz ə ʃɛpɝd." ə ʃɛpɝɾ ɪn ə fænsi koʊt, wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ ɝaʊn ɪm laɪk biz ɝaʊn hʌniɹoʊsəz. "dʒʌst ə ʃɛpɝd." hi taɪɾənd ɪz ɡɹɪp ɪn ðə mænz hɛɹ.

"You fool," Thom breathed. Dena died for this? Oh, Light, she's dead. He felt as if he wanted to cry. "The boy's a shepherd." A shepherd in a fancy coat, with Aes Sedai around him like bees around honeyroses. "Just a shepherd." He tightened his grip in the man's hair.

"weɪt! weɪt! jə kən meɪk mɔɹ ðən ɛni faɪv kɹaʊnz, əɹ ivən tɛn. ə hʌnʒɹəd, mɔɹ laɪk. ɛvɹi haʊs wɑns tə noʊ əbaʊt ðɪs ɹænd ælθɹ. tu əɹ θɹi hæv əpɹoʊtʃt mi. wɪð wʌt jə noʊ, ən maɪ noʊɪŋ u wɑns tə noʊ ɪt, wi kəd boʊθ fɪl əɹ pɑkəts. ən ðəɹ əz bɪn ə wʊmən, ə leɪɾi, aɪ hæv sin mɔɹ ðən wʌns waɪl æskɪŋ æftɝ hɪm. ɪf wi kən faɪn aʊɾ u ʃiz . . . waɪ, wi kəd sɛl ðæt, tu."

"Wait! Wait! You can make more than any five crowns, or even ten. A hundred, more like. Every House wants to know about this Rand al'Thor. Two or three have approached me. With what you know, and my knowing who wants to know it, we could both fill our pockets. And there has been a woman, a lady, I have seen more than once while asking after him. If we can find out who she is . . . why, we could sell that, too."

"juv meɪd wʌn ɹil mɪsteɪk ɪn ɪɾ ɔl," tɑm sɛd.

"You've made one real mistake in it all," Thom said.

"mɪsteɪk?" ðə mænz fɑɹ hænd wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə slaɪd daʊn təwɔɹɾ ɪz bɛlt. noʊ daʊɾ i hæɾ ənʌðɝ dæɡɝ ðɛɹ. tɑm ɪɡnɔɹɾ ɪt.

"Mistake?" The man's far hand was beginning to slide down toward his belt. No doubt he had another dagger there. Thom ignored it.

"ju ʃəd nɛvɝ əv tʌtʃt ðə ɡɝl."

"You should never have touched the girl."

ðə mænz hæn dɑɹɾɪd fəɹ ɪz bɛlt, ðən i ɡeɪv wʌn kənvʌlsɪv stɑɹɾ əz tɑmz naɪf wɛn hoʊm.

The man's hand darted for his belt, then he gave one convulsive start as Thom's knife went home.

tɑm lɛɾ ɪm fɔl oʊvɝ əweɪ fɹəm ðə dɔɹ ən stʊɾ ə moʊmən bɪfɔɹ bɛndɪŋ taɪɹədli tə tʌɡ hɪz bleɪdz fɹi. ðə dɔɹ bæŋd oʊpən, ən i wɝld wɪð ə snɑɹl ɑn ɪz feɪs.

Thom let him fall over away from the door and stood a moment before bending tiredly to tug his blades free. The door banged open, and he whirled with a snarl on his face.

zɛɹə dʒɝk bæk, ə hæn tə hɝ θɹoʊt, stɛɹɪŋ ət hɪm. "ðæt ful ɛlə dʒʌs toʊl mi," ʃi sɛɾ ənstɛɾəli, "ðæt tu ʌv bɑɹθeɪnzəz mɛn wɝ æskɪŋ æftɝ jə læs naɪt, ən wɪð wʌɾ aɪv hɝd ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ. . . . aɪ θɔt jə sɛd jə dɪdn pleɪ ɪn ðə ɡeɪm ɛnimɔɹ."

Zera jerked back, a hand to her throat, staring at him. "That fool Ella just told me," she said unsteadily, "that two of Barthanes's men were asking after you last night, and with what I've heard this morning. . . . I thought you said you didn't play in the Game anymore."

"ðeɪ faʊn mi," hi sɛd wɛɹəli.

"They found me," he said wearily.

hɝ aɪz dʒɹɑp fɹəm ɪz feɪs ən waɪɾənd əz ðeɪ tʊk ɪn ðə bɑɾiz ə ðə tu mɛn. heɪstəli ʃi stɛpt ɪndə ðə ɹum, ʃʌɾɪŋ ðə dɔɹ bɪhaɪn hɝ. "ðɪs ɪz bæd, tɑm. jəl əv tə liv kɛɹhin." hɝ ɡeɪz fɛl ɑn ðə bɛd, ən əɹ bɹɛθ kɑt. "oʊ, noʊ. oʊ, noʊ. oʊ, tɑm, aɪm soʊ sɑɹi."

Her eyes dropped from his face and widened as they took in the bodies of the two men. Hastily she stepped into the room, shutting the door behind her. "This is bad, Thom. You'll have to leave Cairhien." Her gaze fell on the bed, and her breath caught. "Oh, no. Oh, no. Oh, Thom, I'm so sorry."

"aɪ kænɑt liv jɛt, zɛɹə." hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən tɛndɝli dʒɹu ə blæŋkəɾ oʊvɝ dinə, kʌvɝɪŋ əɹ feɪs. "aɪ hæv ənʌðɝ mæn tə kɪl, fɝst."

"I cannot leave yet, Zera." He hesitated, then tenderly drew a blanket over Dena, covering her face. "I have another man to kill, first."

ði ɪnkipɝ ɡeɪv hɝsɛlf ə ʃeɪk ən pʊld əɹ aɪz əweɪ fɹəm ðə bɛd. hɝ vɔɪs wɑz mɔɹ ðən ə lɪɾəl bɹɛθi. "ɪf jə min bɑɹθeɪnz, jəɹ tu leɪt. ɛvɹibɑɾiz tɔkɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪɾ ɔlɹɛɾi. hiz dɛd. hɪz sɝvəns faʊn ɪm ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ, tɔɹn tə pisəz ɪn ɪz bɛdtʃeɪmbɝ. ði oʊnli weɪ ðeɪ nu ɪt wɑz ɪm wɑz ɪz hɛd stʌk ɑn ə spaɪk oʊvɝ ðə faɪɝpleɪs." ʃi leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn ɪz ɑɹm. "tɑm, jə kæn haɪd ðət jə wɝ ðəɹ læs naɪt, nɑt fɹəm ɛnibəɾi hu wɑns tə noʊ. æd ðiz tu ɪn, ən ðɛɹz noʊbɑdi ɪn kɛɹhin u woʊn bɪliv jə wɝ ɪnvɑlvd." ðəɹ wɑz ə slaɪt kwɛstʃənɪŋ noʊɾ ɪn əɹ læst wɝdz, əz ɪf ʃi, tu, wɝ wʌndɝɪŋ.

The innkeeper gave herself a shake and pulled her eyes away from the bed. Her voice was more than a little breathy. "If you mean Barthanes, you're too late. Everybody's talking about it already. He is dead. His servants found him this morning, torn to pieces in his bedchamber. The only way they knew it was him was his head stuck on a spike over the fireplace." She laid a hand on his arm. "Thom, you can't hide that you were there last night, not from anybody who wants to know. Add these two in, and there's nobody in Cairhien who won't believe you were involved." There was a slight questioning note in her last words, as if she, too, were wondering.

"ɪt dʌzn mæɾɝ, aɪ səpoʊz," hi sɛd dʌli. hi kəd nɑt stɑp lʊkɪŋ daʊn ət ðə blæŋkət-kʌvɝd ʃeɪp ɑn ðə bɛd. "pɝhæps əl ɡoʊ bæk tə ændɝ. tə keɪɛmlɪn."

"It doesn't matter, I suppose," he said dully. He could not stop looking down at the blanket-covered shape on the bed. "Perhaps I will go back to Andor. To Caemlyn."

ʃi tʊk ɪz ʃoʊldɝz, tɝnɪŋ ɪm əweɪ fɹəm ðə bɛd. "ju mɛn," ʃi saɪd, "ɔlweɪz θɪŋkɪŋ wɪð iðɝ jəɹ mʌsəlz əɹ jəɹ hɑɹts, ən nɛvɝ jəɹ hɛdz. keɪɛmlɪn ɪz əz bæɾ əz kɛɹhin, fəɹ ju. iðɝ pleɪs, jəl ɛn ʌp dɛd, əɹ ɪn pɹɪzən. dʒju θɪŋk ʃid wɑn ðæt? ɪf jə wɑnə ɑnɝ əɹ mɛmɹi, steɪ əlaɪv."
