She took his shoulders, turning him away from the bed. "You men," she sighed, "always thinking with either your muscles or your hearts, and never your heads. Caemlyn is as bad as Cairhien, for you. Either place, you'll end up dead, or in prison. Do you think she'd want that? If you want to honor her memory, stay alive."

"wɪl jə teɪk kɛɹ ʌv. . . ." hi kəd nɑt seɪ ɪt. ɡɹoʊɪŋ oʊld, hi θɔt. ɡoʊɪŋ sɑft. hi pʊl ðə hɛvi pɝs fɹəm ɪz pɑkəɾ ən foʊldəɾ əɹ hænz ɝaʊn ɪt. "ðɪs ʃəd teɪk kɛɹ ʌv . . . ɛvɹiθɪŋ. ən hɛlp wən ðeɪ stɑɹɾ æskɪŋ kwɛstʃənz əbaʊt mi, tu."

"Will you take care of. . . ." He could not say it. Growing old, he thought. Going soft. He pulled the heavy purse from his pocket and folded her hands around it. "This should take care of . . . everything. And help when they start asking questions about me, too."

"aɪ wɪl si tə ɛvɹiθɪŋ," ʃi sɛd dʒɛnli. "ju mʌst ɡoʊ, tɑm. naʊ."

"I will see to everything," she said gently. "You must go, Thom. Now."

hi nɑɾəd ɹɪlʌktənli, ən sloʊli bɪɡæn stʌfɪŋ ə fju θɪŋz ɪn ə sɛɾ ə sæɾəlbæɡz. waɪl i wɝkt, zɛɹə ɡɑɾ əɹ fɝs kloʊs lʊk ət ðə fæt mæn spɹɔl pɑɹtweɪ ɪn ðə wɔɹdʒɹoʊb, ən ʃi ɡeɪv ə laʊd ɡæsp. hi lʊkt əɾ əɹ ɪnkwaɪɝɪŋli; əz lɔŋ əz i hæd noʊn hɝ, ʃi hæd nɛvɝ bɪn wʌn tə ɡoʊ feɪn oʊvɝ blʌd.

He nodded reluctantly, and slowly began stuffing a few things in a set of saddlebags. While he worked, Zera got her first close look at the fat man sprawled partway in the wardrobe, and she gave a loud gasp. He looked at her inquiringly; as long as he had known her, she had never been one to go faint over blood.

"ðiz ɑɹən bɑɹθeɪnzəz mɛn, tɑm. ət list, ðət wʌn ɪzənt." ʃi nɑɾəd təwɔɹd ðə fæt mæn. "ɪts ðə wɝs kɛp sikɹəɾ ɪn kɛɹhin ðəɾ i wɝks fəɹ haʊs ɹieɪɾən. fəɹ ɡɔlʒɹiən."

"These aren't Barthanes's men, Thom. At least, that one isn't." She nodded toward the fat man. "It's the worst kept secret in Cairhien that he works for House Riatin. For Galldrian."

"ɡɔlʒɹiən," hi sɛd flætli. wʌɾ əz ðət blʌɾi ʃɛpɝd ɡɑɾən mi ɪntu? wʌɾ əv ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɡɑɾən əs boʊθ ɪntu? bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɡɔlʒɹiənz mɛn mɝɾɝd hɝ.

"Galldrian," he said flatly. What has that bloody shepherd gotten me into? What have the Aes Sedai gotten us both into? But it was Galldrian's men murdered her.

ðəɹ mʌst əv bɪn sʌmθɪŋ ə hɪz θɔts ɑn ɪz feɪs. zɛɹə sɛd ʃɑɹpli, "dinə wɑns jə əlaɪv, jə ful! jə tʃɹaɪ tə kɪl ðə kɪŋ, ən jəl bi dɛd bɪfɔɹ jə ɡɛt wɪðɪn ə hʌnʒɹəd spænz ə hɪm, ɪf jə kʌm ðət kloʊs!"

There must have been something of his thoughts on his face. Zera said sharply, "Dena wants you alive, you fool! You try to kill the King, and you'll be dead before you get within a hundred spans of him, if you come that close!"

ə ɹɔɹ keɪm fɹəm ðə sɪɾi wɔlz, əz ɪf hæf ə kɛɹhin wɝ ʃaʊɾɪŋ. fɹaʊnɪŋ, tɑm pɪɹd fɹəm ɪz wɪndoʊ. bɪɑn ðə tɑp ə ðə ɡɹeɪ wɔlz əbʌv ðə ɹuftɑps ə ðə fɔɹɡeɪt, ə θɪk kɑləm ə smoʊk wɑz ɹaɪzɪŋ ɪndə ðə skaɪ. fɑɹ bɪɑn ðə wɔlz. bɪsaɪd ðə fɝs blæk pɪlɝ, ə fju ɡɹeɪ tɛnʒɹəlz kwɪkli ɡɹu ɪndə ənʌðɝ, ən mɔɹ wɪsps əpɪɹd fɝðɝ ɑn. hi ɛstəmeɪɾəd ðə dɪstəns ən tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ.

A roar came from the city walls, as if half of Cairhien were shouting. Frowning, Thom peered from his window. Beyond the top of the gray walls above the rooftops of the Foregate, a thick column of smoke was rising into the sky. Far beyond the walls. Beside the first black pillar, a few gray tendrils quickly grew into another, and more wisps appeared further on. He estimated the distance and took a deep breath.

"pɝhæps jə hæd bɛɾɝ θɪŋk əbaʊt livɪŋ, tu. ɪt lʊks əz ɪf sʌmwʌn ɪz faɪɹɪŋ ðə ɡɹænɛɝiz."

"Perhaps you had better think about leaving, too. It looks as if someone is firing the granaries."

"aɪ hæv lɪv θɹu ɹaɪəts bɪfɔɹ. ɡoʊ naʊ, tɑm." wɪð ə læs lʊk ət dinəz ʃɹaʊɾɪd fɔɹm, hi ɡæðɝɾ ɪz θɪŋz, bʌɾ əz i stɑɹɾəd tə liv, zɛɹə spoʊk əɡɛn. "ju hæv ə deɪnʒɝəs lʊk ɪn jəɹ aɪz, tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn. ɪmædʒən dinə sɪɾɪŋ hɪɹ, əlaɪv ən heɪl. θɪŋk wʌt ʃi wəd seɪ. wəd ʃi lɛt jə ɡoʊ ɔf ən ɡɛt jɝsɛlf kɪl tə noʊ pɝpəs?"

"I have lived through riots before. Go now, Thom." With a last look at Dena's shrouded form, he gathered his things, but as he started to leave, Zera spoke again. "You have a dangerous look in your eyes, Thom Merrilin. Imagine Dena sitting here, alive and hale. Think what she would say. Would she let you go off and get yourself killed to no purpose?"

"aɪm oʊnli ən oʊld ɡlimən," hi sɛd fɹəm ðə dɔɹ. ən ɹænd ælθɹ ɪz oʊnli ə ʃɛpɝd, bʌt wi boʊθ də wʌt wi mʌst. "hu kəɾ aɪ pɑsəbli bi deɪnʒɝəs tə?"

"I'm only an old gleeman," he said from the door. And Rand al'Thor is only a shepherd, but we both do what we must. "Who could I possibly be dangerous to?"

əz i pʊl ðə dɔɹ tə, haɪɾɪŋ hɝ, haɪɾɪŋ dinə, ə mɝθləs, wʊlfɪʃ ɡɹɪn keɪm ɑntu hɪz feɪs. hɪz lɛɡ hɝt, bʌɾ i bɛɹli fɛlt ɪɾ əz i hɝid pɝpəsfəli daʊn ðə stɛɹz ən aʊɾ ə ði ɪn.

As he pulled the door to, hiding her, hiding Dena, a mirthless, wolfish grin came onto his face. His leg hurt, but he barely felt it as he hurried purposefully down the stairs and out of the inn.

pdən feɪn ɹeɪn ɪn ɪz hɔɹs ətɑp ə hɪl əbʌv fɑlm, ɪn wʌn ə ðə fju spɑɹs θɪkəts ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ ɑn ðə hɪlz aʊtsaɪd ðə taʊn. ðə pæk hɔɹs bɛɹɪŋ ɪz pɹɛʃəs bɝɾən bʌmpt ɪz lɛɡ, ən i kɪkt ɪɾ ɪn ðə ɹɪbz wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ; ði ænəməl snɔɹɾɪd ən dʒɝk bæk tə ði ɛn ə ðə lɛɾ i hæd taɪd tə hɪz sæɾəl. ðə wʊmən hæd nɑt wɑntəd tə ɡɪv ʌp əɹ hɔɹs, noʊ mɔɹ ðən ɛni ʌv ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz u hæd fɑloʊɾ ɪm hæd wɑntəd tə bi lɛft əloʊn ɪn ðə hɪlz wɪð ðə tʃɹɑləks, wɪθaʊt feɪnz pɹətɛktɪŋ pɹɛzəns. hi hæd sɑlv boʊθ pɹɑbləmz izəli. miɾ ɪn ə tʃɹɑlɑk kʊkpɑt hæd noʊ niɾ ʌv ə hɔɹs. ðə wʊmənz kəmpænjənz hæd bɪn ʃeɪkən baɪ ðə dʒɝni əlɔŋ ðə weɪz, tə ə weɪɡeɪɾ aʊtsaɪɾ ə lɔŋ-əbændən stɛɾɪŋ ɑn toʊmən hɛd, ən wɑtʃɪŋ ðə tʃɹɑləks pɹipɛɹ ðɛɹ dɪnɝ hæd meɪd ðə sɝvaɪvɪŋ dɑɹkfɹɛnz ɪkstʃɹimli bɪɾəbəl.

Padan Fain reined in his horse atop a hill above Falme, in one of the few sparse thickets remaining on the hills outside the town. The pack horse bearing his precious burden bumped his leg, and he kicked it in the ribs without looking; the animal snorted and jerked back to the end of the lead he had tied to his saddle. The woman had not wanted to give up her horse, no more than any of the Darkfriends who had followed him had wanted to be left alone in the hills with the Trollocs, without Fain's protecting presence. He had solved both problems easily. Meat in a Trolloc cookpot had no need of a horse. The woman's companions had been shaken by the journey along the Ways, to a Waygate outside a long-abandoned stedding on Toman Head, and watching the Trollocs prepare their dinner had made the surviving Darkfriends extremely biddable.

fɹəm ði ɛdʒ ə ðə tʃɹiz, feɪn stʌɾid ði ənwɔl taʊn ən snɪɹd. wʌn ʃɔɹt mɝtʃən tʃɹeɪn wɑz ɹʌmbəlɪŋ ɪn əmʌŋ ðə steɪbəlz ən hɔɹs lɑts ən wæɡən jɑɹdz ðət bɔɹɾɝd ðə taʊn, waɪl ənʌðɝ ɹʌmbəld aʊt, ɹeɪzɪŋ lɪɾəl dʌs fɹəm dɝt pæk baɪ mɛni jɪɹz ə sətʃ tʃɹæfɪk. ðə mɛn dʒɹaɪvɪŋ ðə wæɡənz ən ðə fju ɹaɪɾɪŋ bɪsaɪɾ əm wɝ ɔl loʊkəl mɛn baɪ ðɛɹ kloʊðɪŋ, jɛt ðə maʊntəd mɛn, ət list, hæd sɔɹdz ɑn bælʒɹɪks, ən ivən ə fju spɪɹz ən baʊz. ðə soʊlʒɝz i sɔ, ən ðəɹ wɝ fju, dɪd nɑt sim tə bi wɑtʃɪŋ ði ɑɹmd mɛn ðeɪ hæd səpoʊzədli kɑŋkɝd.

From the edge of the trees, Fain studied the unwalled town and sneered. One short merchant train was rumbling in among the stables and horse lots and wagon yards that bordered the town, while another rumbled out, raising little dust from dirt packed by many years of such traffic. The men driving the wagons and the few riding beside them were all local men by their clothing, yet the mounted men, at least, had swords on baldrics, and even a few spears and bows. The soldiers he saw, and there were few, did not seem to be watching the armed men they had supposedly conquered.

hi hæd lɝn sʌmθɪŋ ə ðiz pipəl, ðiz sintʃæn, ɪn ɪz deɪ ən ə naɪɾ ɑn toʊmən hɛd. ət list, əz mʌtʃ əz ðə dɪfiɾəd foʊk nu. ɪt wɑz nɛvɝ hɑɹd tə faɪn sʌmwʌn əloʊn, ən ðeɪ ɔlweɪz ænsɝd kwɛstʃənz pɹɑpɝli pʊt. mɛn ɡæðɝd mɔɹ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən ɑn ði ɪnveɪɾɝz, əz ɪf ðeɪ æktʃəli  bɪliv ðeɪ wəɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli də sʌmθɪŋ wɪð wʌt ðeɪ nu, bʌt ðeɪ səmtaɪmz tʃɹaɪd tə hoʊl bæk. wɪmən, baɪ ən lɑɹdʒ, simd ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn wɪð ðɛɹ lɪvz huɛvɝ ðɛɹ ɹulɝz wɝ, jɛt ðeɪ noʊɾəd dɪteɪlz mɛn dɪd nɑt, ən ðeɪ tɔk mɔɹ kwɪkli wʌns ðeɪ stɑp skɹimɪŋ. tʃɪlʒɹən tɔk ðə kwɪkɪst ʌv ɔl, bʌt ðeɪ sɛldəm sɛd mʌtʃ ðət wɑz wɝθwaɪl.

He had learned something of these people, these Seanchan, in his day and a night on Toman Head. At least, as much as the defeated folk knew. It was never hard to find someone alone, and they always answered questions properly put. Men gathered more information on the invaders, as if they actually believed they would eventually do something with what they knew, but they sometimes tried to hold back. Women, by and large, seemed interested in going on with their lives whoever their rulers were, yet they noted details men did not, and they talked more quickly once they stopped screaming. Children talked the quickest of all, but they seldom said much that was worthwhile.

hi hæd dɪskɑɹɾɪd θɹi kɔɹɾɝz ʌv wʌɾ i hæd hɝɾ əz nɑnsɛns ən ɹumɝz ɡɹoʊɪŋ ɪndə feɪbəlz, bʌɾ i tʊk səm ə ðoʊz kənkluʒənz bæk, naʊ. ɛniwʌn əɾ ɔl kəɾ ɛntɝ fɑlm, ɪɾ əpɪɹd. wɪð ə stɑɹt, hi sɔ ðə tʃɹuθ ʌv ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ "nɑnsɛns" əz twɛnti soʊlʒɝz ɹoʊɾ aʊɾ ə ðə taʊn. hi kəd nɑt meɪk aʊt ðɛɹ maʊns klɪɹli, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ sɝɾənli nɑt hɔɹsəz. ðeɪ ɹæn wɪð ə fluəd ɡɹeɪs, ən ðɛɹ dɑɹk skɪnz sim tə hæv ə ɡlɪn ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ sʌn, əz ə skeɪlz. hi kɹeɪn ɪz nɛk tə wɑtʃ əm dɪsəpɪɹ ɪnlænd, ðən buɾɪd ɪz hɔɹs təwɔɹd ðə taʊn.

He had discarded three quarters of what he had heard as nonsense and rumors growing into fables, but he took some of those conclusions back, now. Anyone at all could enter Falme, it appeared. With a start, he saw the truth of a little more "nonsense" as twenty soldiers rode out of the town. He could not make out their mounts clearly, but they were certainly not horses. They ran with a fluid grace, and their dark skins seemed to have a glint in the morning sun, as of scales. He craned his neck to watch them disappear inland, then booted his horse toward the town.

ðə loʊkəl foʊk əmʌŋ ðə steɪbəlz ən pɑɹkt wæɡənz ən fɛns hɔɹs lɑts ɡeɪv ɪm noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə ɡlæns əɹ tu. hi hæd noʊ ɪntʃɹəst ɪn ðɛm, iðɝ; hi ɹoʊɾ ɑn ɪndə ðə taʊn, ɑntu ɪts kɑbəlstoʊn stʃɹits sloʊpɪŋ daʊn tə ðə hɑɹbɝ. hi kəd si ðə hɑɹbɝ klɪɹli, ən ðə lɑɹdʒ, ɑdli ʃeɪp sintʃæn ʃɪps æŋkɝd ðɛɹ. noʊ wʌn bɑðɝɾ ɪm əz i sɝtʃt stʃɹits ðət wɝ niðɝ kɹaʊɾəd nɔɹ ɛmpti. ðəɹ wɝ mɔɹ sintʃæn soʊlʒɝz hɪɹ. ðə pipəl hɝiɾ əbaʊt ðɛɹ bɪznəs wɪð aɪz daʊn, boʊɪŋ wɛnɛvɝ soʊlʒɝz pæst, bʌt ðə sintʃæn peɪɾ əm noʊ maɪnd. ɪɾ ɔl sim pisfəl ɑn ðə sɝfəs, dɪspaɪt ði ɑɹmɝd sintʃæn ɪn ðə stʃɹits ən ðə ʃɪps ɪn ðə hɑɹbɝ, bʌt feɪn kəd sɛns ðə tɛnʃən ʌndɝniθ. hi ɔlweɪz dɪd wɛl wɛɹ mɛn wɝ tɛns ən əfɹeɪd.

The local folk among the stables and parked wagons and fenced horse lots gave him no more than a glance or two. He had no interest in them, either; he rode on into the town, onto its cobblestone streets sloping down to the harbor. He could see the harbor clearly, and the large, oddly shaped Seanchan ships anchored there. No one bothered him as he searched streets that were neither crowded nor empty. There were more Seanchan soldiers here. The people hurried about their business with eyes down, bowing whenever soldiers passed, but the Seanchan paid them no mind. It all seemed peaceful on the surface, despite the armored Seanchan in the streets and the ships in the harbor, but Fain could sense the tension underneath. He always did well where men were tense and afraid.

hi keɪm tə ə lɑɹdʒ haʊs wɪð mɔɹ ðən ə dʌzən soʊlʒɝz stændɪŋ ɡɑɹd bɪfɔɹ ɪt. feɪn stɑpt ən dɪsmaʊntɪd. ɪksɛp fəɹ wʌn ɑbviəs ɔfəsɝ, moʊst wɔɹ ɑɹmɝ ʌv ʌnɹiliv blæk, ən ðɛɹ hɛlməts meɪɾ ɪm θɪŋk ə loʊkəsts' hɛdz. tu lɛðɝi-skɪn bists wɪð θɹi aɪz ən hɔɹni biks ɪnstɛɾ ə maʊðz flæŋk ðə fɹʌn dɔɹ, skwɑɾɪŋ laɪk kɹaʊtʃɪŋ fɹɑɡz; ðə soʊlʒɝ stændɪŋ baɪ itʃ ə ðə kɹitʃɝz hæd θɹi aɪz peɪntəɾ ɑn ðə bɹɛst ə hɪz ɑɹmɝ. feɪn aɪd ðə blu-bɔɹɾɝd bænɝ flæpɪŋ əbʌv ðə ɹuf, ðə spɹɛd-wɪŋ hɔk klʌtʃɪŋ laɪtnɪŋ boʊls, ən tʃɔɹɾəld ɪnsaɪd hɪmsɛlf.

He came to a large house with more than a dozen soldiers standing guard before it. Fain stopped and dismounted. Except for one obvious officer, most wore armor of unrelieved black, and their helmets made him think of locusts' heads. Two leathery-skinned beasts with three eyes and horny beaks instead of mouths flanked the front door, squatting like crouching frogs; the soldier standing by each of the creatures had three eyes painted on the breast of his armor. Fain eyed the blue-bordered banner flapping above the roof, the spread-winged hawk clutching lightning bolts, and chortled inside himself.

wɪmən wɛn ɪn ən aʊɾ ʌv ə haʊs əkɹɔs ðə stʃɹit, wɪmən lɪŋk baɪ sɪlvɝ liʃɪz, bʌɾ i ɪɡnɔɹd ðɛm. hi nu əbaʊt deɪmeɪn fɹəm ðə vɪlɪdʒɝz. ðeɪ maɪt bi ʌv səm jus leɪɾɝ, bʌt nɑt naʊ.

Women went in and out of a house across the street, women linked by silver leashes, but he ignored them. He knew about damane from the villagers. They might be of some use later, but not now.

ðə soʊlʒɝz wɝ lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm, ɪspɛʃli ði ɔfəsɝ, huz ɑɹmɝ wɑz ɔl ɡoʊld ən ɹɛɾ ən ɡɹin.

The soldiers were looking at him, especially the officer, whose armor was all gold and red and green.

fɔɹsɪŋ ən ɪnɡɹeɪʃieɪɾɪŋ smaɪl ɑntu hɪz feɪs, feɪn meɪd hɪmsɛlf baʊ dipli. "maɪ lɔɹdz, aɪ hæv sʌmθɪŋ hɪɹ ðət wɪl ɪntʃɹəs jəɹ ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd. aɪ əʃʊɹ ju, hɪl wɑnə si ɪt, ən mi, pɝsənəli." hi dʒɛstʃɝd tə ðə skwɛɹɪʃ ʃeɪp ɑn ɪz pæk hɔɹs, stɪl ɹæpt ɪn ðə hjudʒ, stʃɹaɪp blæŋkəɾ ɪn wɪtʃ ɪz pipəl hæd faʊn ɪt.

Forcing an ingratiating smile onto his face, Fain made himself bow deeply. "My lords, I have something here that will interest your Great Lord. I assure you, he will want to see it, and me, personally." He gestured to the squarish shape on his pack horse, still wrapped in the huge, striped blanket in which his people had found it.

ði ɔfəsɝ stɛɹɾ ɪm ʌp ən daʊn. "ju saʊn ə fɔɹənɝ tə ðɪs lænd. hæv jə teɪkən ði oʊðz?"

The officer stared him up and down. "You sound a foreigner to this land. Have you taken the oaths?"

"aɪ oʊbeɪ, əweɪt, ən wɪl sɝv," feɪn ɹɪplaɪd smuðli. ɛvɹiwʌn i hæd kwɛstʃən spoʊk ə ði oʊðz, ðoʊ nʌn hæɾ ʌndɝstʊd wʌt ðeɪ mɛnt. ɪf ðiz pipəl wɑntəɾ oʊðz, hi wɑz pɹipɛɹd tə swɛɹ ɛniθɪŋ. hi hæd lɔŋ sɪns lɔs kaʊn ə ði oʊðz i hæd teɪkən.

"I obey, await, and will serve," Fain replied smoothly. Everyone he had questioned spoke of the oaths, though none had understood what they meant. If these people wanted oaths, he was prepared to swear anything. He had long since lost count of the oaths he had taken.

ði ɔfəsɝ moʊʃən tu ʌv ɪz mɛn tə si wʌt wɑz ʌndɝ ðə blæŋkət. sɝpɹaɪzd ɡɹʌns ət ðə weɪɾ əz ðeɪ lɪftəɾ ɪt daʊn fɹəm ðə pæksæɾəl tɝn tə ɡæsps wən ðeɪ stʃɹɪp ðə blæŋkəɾ əweɪ. ði ɔfəsɝ stɛɹd wɪð noʊ ɪkspɹɛʃən ɑn ɪz feɪs ət ðə sɪlvɝ-wɝkt ɡoʊldən tʃɛst ɹɛstɪŋ ɑn ðə kɑbəlstoʊnz, ðən lʊkt ət feɪn. "ə ɡɪft fɪt fəɹ ði ɛmpɹɛs hɝsɛlf. jəl kʌm wɪð mi."

The officer motioned two of his men to see what was under the blanket. Surprised grunts at the weight as they lifted it down from the packsaddle turned to gasps when they stripped the blanket away. The officer stared with no expression on his face at the silver-worked golden chest resting on the cobblestones, then looked at Fain. "A gift fit for the Empress herself. You will come with me."

wʌn ə ðə soʊlʒɝz sɝtʃt feɪn ɹʌfli, bʌɾ i ɛndʒjʊɹɾ ɪɾ ɪn saɪləns, noʊɾɪŋ ðət ði ɔfəsɝ ən ðə tu soʊlʒɝz u tʊk ʌp ðə tʃɛst sɝɛndɝd ðɛɹ sɔɹdz ən dæɡɝz bɪfɔɹ ɡoʊɪŋ ɪnsaɪd. ɛniθɪŋ i kəd lɝn ə ðiz pipəl, haʊɛvɝ smɔl, maɪt hɛlp, ðoʊ hi wɑz kɑnfəɾənt ə hɪz plæn ɔlɹɛɾi. hi wɑz ɔlweɪz kɑnfəɾənt, bʌt nɛvɝ mɔɹ ðən wɛɹ lɔɹdz fɪɹɾ ən əsæsənz naɪf fɹəm ðɛɹ oʊn fɑloʊɝz.

One of the soldiers searched Fain roughly, but he endured it in silence, noting that the officer and the two soldiers who took up the chest surrendered their swords and daggers before going inside. Anything he could learn of these people, however small, might help, though he was confident of his plan already. He was always confident, but never more than where lords feared an assassin's knife from their own followers.

əz ðeɪ wɛn θɹu ðə dɔɹ, ði ɔfəsɝ fɹaʊn ət hɪm, ən fəɹ ə moʊmən feɪn wʌndɝd waɪ. ʌv kɔɹs. ðə bists. wʌtɛvɝ ðeɪ wɝ, ðeɪ wɝ sɝɾənli noʊ wɝs ðən tʃɹɑləks, nʌθɪŋ əɾ ɔl bɪsaɪɾ ə mɹdʒɹɑl, ən i hæd nɑt ɡɪvən əm ə sɛkən lʊk. ɪt wɑz tu leɪt tə pɹitɛn tə bi əfɹeɪɾ ə ðɛm naʊ. bʌt ðə sintʃæn sɛd nʌθɪŋ, oʊnli lɛɾ ɪm dipɝ ɪndə ðə haʊs.

As they went through the door, the officer frowned at him, and for a moment Fain wondered why. Of course. The beasts. Whatever they were, they were certainly no worse than Trollocs, nothing at all beside a Myrddraal, and he had not given them a second look. It was too late to pretend to be afraid of them now. But the Seanchan said nothing, only led him deeper into the house.

ən soʊ feɪn faʊn hɪmsɛlf ɑn ɪz feɪs, ɪn ə ɹum bɛɹ ə fɝnɪʃɪŋz ɪksɛp fəɹ foʊldɪŋ skɹinz ðət hɪɾ ɪts wɔlz, waɪl ði ɔfəsɝ toʊl ðə haɪ lɔɹd tʃɹɑk ə hɪm ən ɪz ɔfɝɪŋ. sɝvəns bɹɔɾ ə teɪbəl ɑn wɪtʃ tə sɛt ðə tʃɛst soʊ ðə haɪ lɔɹd wəɾ əv noʊ nid tə stup; ɔl feɪn sɔ ʌv əm wɝ skɝiɪŋ slɪpɝz. hi baɪɾɪd ɪz taɪm ɪmpeɪʃənli. ɪvɛntʃəwəli ðəɹ wəd kʌm ə taɪm wən i wɑz nɑt ðə wʌn tə baʊ.

And so Fain found himself on his face, in a room bare of furnishings except for folding screens that hid its walls, while the officer told the High Lord Turak of him and his offering. Servants brought a table on which to set the chest so the High Lord would have no need to stoop; all Fain saw of them were scurrying slippers. He bided his time impatiently. Eventually there would come a time when he was not the one to bow.

ðən ðə soʊlʒɝz wɝ dɪsmɪst, ən feɪn toʊl tə ɹaɪz. hi dɪd soʊ sloʊli, stʌɾiɪŋ boʊθ ðə haɪ lɔɹd, wɪð ɪz ʃeɪvən hɛɾ ən ɪz lɔŋ fɪŋɡɝneɪlz ən ɪz blu sɪlk ɹoʊb bɹoʊkeɪɾɪd wɪð blɑsəmz, ən ðə mæn u stʊd bɪsaɪɾ ɪm wɪð ði ənʃeɪvən hæf ə hɪz peɪl hɛɹ ɪn ə lɔŋ bɹeɪd. feɪn wɑz ʃʊɹ ðə fɛloʊ ɪn ɡɹin wɑz oʊnli ə sɝvənt, haʊɛvɝ ɡɹeɪt, bʌt sɝvəns kəd bi jusfəl, ɪspɛʃli ɪf ðeɪ stʊd haɪ ɪn ðɛɹ mæstɝz saɪt.

Then the soldiers were dismissed, and Fain told to rise. He did so slowly, studying both the High Lord, with his shaven head and his long fingernails and his blue silk robe brocaded with blossoms, and the man who stood beside him with the unshaven half of his pale hair in a long braid. Fain was sure the fellow in green was only a servant, however great, but servants could be useful, especially if they stood high in their master's sight.

"ə mɑɹvələs ɡɪft." tʃɹɑks aɪz lɪftəd fɹəm ðə tʃɛs tə feɪn. ə sɛn ə ɹoʊzɪz wɑftɪd fɹəm ðə haɪ lɔɹd. "jɛt ðə kwɛstʃən æsks ɪtsɛlf; haʊ dɪd wʌn laɪk jə kʌm baɪ ə tʃɛs mɛni lɛsɝ lɔɹdz kəd nɑɾ əfɔɹd? ɑɹ jə ə θif?"

"A marvelous gift." Turak's eyes lifted from the chest to Fain. A scent of roses wafted from the High Lord. "Yet the question asks itself; how did one like you come by a chest many lesser lords could not afford? Are you a thief?"

feɪn tʌɡd əɾ ɪz wɔɹn, nʌn-tu-klin koʊt. "ɪɾ ɪz səmtaɪmz nɛsəsɛɹi fəɹ ə mæn tə əpɪɹ lɛs ðən i ɪz, haɪ lɔɹd. maɪ pɹɛzənt ʃæbaɪnəs əlaʊd mi tə bɹɪŋ ðɪs tə jə ʌnməlɛstɪd. ðɪs tʃɛst ɪz oʊld, haɪ lɔɹd - əz oʊld əz ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz - ən wɪðɪn ɪt laɪz ə tʃɹɛʒɝ sətʃ əz fju aɪz əv ɛvɝ sin. sun - vɛɹi sun, haɪ lɔɹd - əl bi eɪbəl tə oʊpən ɪt, ən ɡɪv jə ðət wɪtʃ wɪl ɛneɪbəl jə tə teɪk ðɪs læn əz fɑɹ əz jə wɪʃ, tə ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝld, ði il weɪst, ðə lænz bɪɑnd. nʌθɪŋ wɪl stæn əɡɛns ju, haɪ lɔɹd, wʌns aɪ - " hi kʌɾ ɔf əz tʃɹɑk bɪɡæn ɹʌnɪŋ ɪz lɔŋ-neɪl fɪŋɡɝz oʊvɝ ðə tʃɛst.

Fain tugged at his worn, none-too-clean coat. "It is sometimes necessary for a man to appear less than he is, High Lord. My present shabbiness allowed me to bring this to you unmolested. This chest is old, High Lord - as old as the Age of Legends - and within it lies a treasure such as few eyes have ever seen. Soon - very soon, High Lord - I will be able to open it, and give you that which will enable you to take this land as far as you wish, to the Spine of the World, the Aiel Waste, the lands beyond. Nothing will stand against you, High Lord, once I - " He cut off as Turak began running his long-nailed fingers over the chest.

"aɪ hæv sin tʃɛsts sətʃ əz ðɪs, tʃɛsts fɹəm ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz," ðə haɪ lɔɹd sɛd, "ðoʊ nʌn soʊ faɪn. ðeɪ ɑɹ mɛn tə bi oʊpən oʊnli baɪ ðoʊz u noʊ ðə pæɾɝn, bʌɾ aɪ - ɑ!" hi pɹɛst əmʌŋ ði ɔɹneɪt wɝlz ən bɔsɪz, ðəɹ wɑz ə ʃɑɹp klɪk, ən i lɪftəd bæk ðə lɪd. ə flɪkɝ ʌv wʌt maɪɾ əv bɪn dɪsəpɔɪnmənt pæst əkɹɔs ɪz feɪs.

"I have seen chests such as this, chests from the Age of Legends," the High Lord said, "though none so fine. They are meant to be opened only by those who know the pattern, but I - ah!" He pressed among the ornate whorls and bosses, there was a sharp click, and he lifted back the lid. A flicker of what might have been disappointment passed across his face.

feɪn bɪt ði ɪnsaɪɾ ə hɪz maʊθ tɪl blʌd keɪm tə kip fɹəm snɑɹlɪŋ. ɪt lɛsən ɪz bɑɹɡɪnɪŋ pəzɪʃən ðəɾ i wɑz nɑt ðə wʌn u hæɾ oʊpən ðə tʃɛst. stɪl, ɔl ðə ɹɛs kəd ɡoʊ əz i hæd plæn ɪf i kəɾ oʊnli meɪk hɪmsɛlf bi peɪʃənt. bʌɾ i hæd bɪn peɪʃən soʊ lɔŋ.

Fain bit the inside of his mouth till blood came to keep from snarling. It lessened his bargaining position that he was not the one who had opened the chest. Still, all the rest could go as he had planned if he could only make himself be patient. But he had been patient so long.

"ðiz ɑɹ tʃɹɛʒɝz fɹəm ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz?" tʃɹɑk sɛd, lɪftɪŋ aʊt ðə kɝl hɔɹn ɪn wʌn hæn ən ðə kɝv dæɡɝ wɪð ðə ɹubi ɪn ɪts ɡoʊldən hɪlt ɪn ði ʌðɝ. feɪn klʌtʃt ɪz hænz ɪn fɪsts əɾ ɪz saɪdz soʊ hi wəd nɑt ɡɹæb ðə dæɡɝ. "ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz," tʃɹɑk ɹɪpiɾɪd sɔfli, tʃɹeɪsɪŋ ðə sɪlvɝ skɹɪpt ɪnleɪɾ ɝaʊn ðə ɡoʊldən bɛl ə ðə hɔɹn wɪð ðə tɪp ə ðə dæɡɝz bleɪd. hɪz bɹaʊz ɹoʊz ɪn stɑɹɾəlmənt, ðə fɝst oʊpən ɪkspɹɛʃən feɪn hæd sin fɹəm hɪm, bʌɾ ɪn ðə nɛkst ɪnstən tʃɹɑks feɪs wɑz əz smuð əz ɛvɝ. "du juv ɛni aɪdiə wʌt ðɪs ɪz?"

"These are treasures from the Age of Legends?" Turak said, lifting out the curled Horn in one hand and the curved dagger with the ruby in its golden hilt in the other. Fain clutched his hands in fists at his sides so he would not grab the dagger. "The Age of Legends," Turak repeated softly, tracing the silver script inlaid around the golden bell of the Horn with the tip of the dagger's blade. His brows rose in startlement, the first open expression Fain had seen from him, but in the next instant Turak's face was as smooth as ever. "Do you have any idea what this is?"

"ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ, haɪ lɔɹd," feɪn sɛd smuðli, pliz tə si ðə maʊθ ə ðə mæn wɪð ðə bɹeɪd dʒɹɑp oʊpən. tʃɹɑk oʊnli nɑɾəd əz ɪf tə hɪmsɛlf.

"The Horn of Valere, High Lord," Fain said smoothly, pleased to see the mouth of the man with the braid drop open. Turak only nodded as if to himself.

ðə haɪ lɔɹd tɝn əweɪ. feɪn blɪŋkt ən oʊpən ɪz maʊθ, ðɛn, əɾ ə ʃɑɹp dʒɛstʃɝ fɹəm ðə jɛloʊ-hɛɹd mæn, fɑloʊd wɪθaʊt spikɪŋ.

The High Lord turned away. Fain blinked and opened his mouth, then, at a sharp gesture from the yellow-haired man, followed without speaking.

ɪt wɑz ənʌðɝ ɹum wɪð ɔl ði ɝɪdʒənəl fɝnɪʃɪŋz ɡɔn, ɹipleɪs baɪ foʊldɪŋ skɹinz ən ə sɪŋɡəl tʃɛɹ feɪsɪŋ ə tɔl ɹaʊn kæbənət. stɪl hoʊldɪŋ ðə hɔɹn ən ðə dæɡɝ, tʃɹɑk lʊkt ət ðə kæbənət, ðən əweɪ. hi sɛd nʌθɪŋ, bʌt ði ʌðɝ sintʃæn snæp kwɪk ɔɹɾɝz, ən ɪn moʊməns mɛn ɪn pleɪn wʊlən ɹoʊbz əpɪɹd θɹu ə dɔɹ bɪhaɪn ðə skɹinz bɛɹɪŋ ənʌðɝ smɔl teɪbəl. ə jʌŋ wʊmən wɪð hɛɹ soʊ peɪl ɪt wɑz ɔlmoʊst waɪt keɪm bɪhaɪn ðɛm, hɝ ɑɹmz fʊl ə smɔl stænz ə pɑlɪʃt wʊɾ ɪn vɛɹiəs saɪzəz ən ʃeɪps. hɝ ɡɑɹmənt wɑz waɪt sɪlk, ən soʊ θɪn ðət feɪn kəd si hɝ bɑɾi klɪɹli θɹu ɪt, bʌɾ i hæɾ aɪz oʊnli fəɹ ðə dæɡɝ. ðə hɔɹn wɑz ə minz tə ən ɛnd, bʌt ðə dæɡɝ wɑz ə pɑɹɾ ə hɪm.

It was another room with all the original furnishings gone, replaced by folding screens and a single chair facing a tall round cabinet. Still holding the Horn and the dagger, Turak looked at the cabinet, then away. He said nothing, but the other Seanchan snapped quick orders, and in moments men in plain woolen robes appeared through a door behind the screens bearing another small table. A young woman with hair so pale it was almost white came behind them, her arms full of small stands of polished wood in various sizes and shapes. Her garment was white silk, and so thin that Fain could see her body clearly through it, but he had eyes only for the dagger. The Horn was a means to an end, but the dagger was a part of him.

tʃɹɑk bɹifli tʌtʃt wʌn ə ðə wʊɾən stænz ðə ɡɝl hɛld, ən ʃi pleɪst ɪɾ ɑn ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə teɪbəl. ðə mɛn tɝn ðə tʃɛɹ tə feɪs ɪɾ ʌndɝ ðə dɝɛkʃən ə ðə mæn wɪð ðə bɹeɪd. ðə loʊɝ sɝvəns' hɛɹ hʌŋ tə ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz. ðeɪ skɝiɾ aʊt wɪð baʊz ðəɾ ɔlmoʊs pʊt ðɛɹ hɛdz ɑn ðɛɹ niz.

Turak briefly touched one of the wooden stands the girl held, and she placed it on the center of the table. The men turned the chair to face it under the direction of the man with the braid. The lower servants' hair hung to their shoulders. They scurried out with bows that almost put their heads on their knees.

pleɪsɪŋ ðə hɔɹn ɑn ðə stæn soʊ ðəɾ ɪt stʊɾ əpɹaɪt, tʃɹɑk leɪd ðə dæɡɝ ɑn ðə teɪbəl ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɪɾ ən wɛn tə sɪɾ ɪn ðə tʃɛɹ.

Placing the Horn on the stand so that it stood upright, Turak laid the dagger on the table in front of it and went to sit in the chair.

feɪn kəd stæn ɪt noʊ lɔŋɡɝ. hi ɹitʃt fəɹ ðə dæɡɝ.

Fain could stand it no longer. He reached for the dagger.

ðə jɛloʊ-hɛɹd mæn kɑɾ ɪz ɹɪst ɪn ə kɹʌʃɪŋ ɡɹɪp. "ənʃeɪvən dɔɡ! noʊ ðət ðə hæn ðət tʌtʃəz ðə pɹɑpɝɾi ʌv ðə haɪ lɔɹɾ ənbɪddən ɪz kʌɾ ɔf."

The yellow-haired man caught his wrist in a crushing grip. "Unshaven dog! Know that the hand that touches the property of the High Lord unbidden is cut off."

"ɪɾ ɪz maɪn," feɪn ɡɹaʊld. peɪʃəns! soʊ lɔŋ.

"It is mine," Fain growled. Patience! So long.

tʃɹɑk, laʊnʒɪŋ bæk ɪn ðə tʃɛɹ, lɪftəd wʌn blu-lækɝd fɪŋɡɝneɪl, ən feɪn wɑz pʊld aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ soʊ ðə haɪ lɔɹd kəd vju ðə hɔɹn ʌnəbstʃɹʌktɪd.

Turak, lounging back in the chair, lifted one blue-lacquered fingernail, and Fain was pulled out of the way so the High Lord could view the Horn unobstructed.

"jʊɹz?" tʃɹɑk sɛd. "ɪnsaɪɾ ə tʃɛs jə kəd nɑɾ oʊpən? ɪf jə ɪntʃɹəs mi səfɪʃənli, aɪ meɪ ɡɪv jə ðə dæɡɝ. ivən ɪf ɪts fɹəm ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz, aɪ hæv noʊ ɪntʃɹəst ɪn sətʃ əz ðæt. bɪfɔɹ ɔl ɛls, jəl ænsɝ mi ə kwɛstʃən. waɪ hæv jə bɹɔt ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ tə mi?"

"Yours?" Turak said. "Inside a chest you could not open? If you interest me sufficiently, I may give you the dagger. Even if it is from the Age of Legends, I have no interest in such as that. Before all else, you will answer me a question. Why have you brought the Horn of Valere to me?"

feɪn aɪd ðə dæɡɝ lɔŋɪŋli ə moʊmən mɔɹ, ðən dʒɝkt ɪz ɹɪs fɹi ən ɹʌbd ɪɾ əz i baʊd. "ðæt jə meɪ saʊn ɪt, haɪ lɔɹd. ðən jə meɪ teɪk ɔl ə ðɪs lænd, ɪf jə wɪʃ. ɔl ə ðə wɝld. jə meɪ bɹeɪk ðə waɪt taʊɝ ən ɡɹaɪn ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tə dʌst, fəɹ ivən ðɛɹ paʊɝz kænɑt stɑp hɪɹoʊz kʌm bæk fɹəm ðə dɛd."

Fain eyed the dagger longingly a moment more, then jerked his wrist free and rubbed it as he bowed. "That you may sound it, High Lord. Then you may take all of this land, if you wish. All of the world. You may break the White Tower and grind the Aes Sedai to dust, for even their powers cannot stop heroes come back from the dead."

"aɪ æm tə saʊn ɪt." tʃɹɑks toʊn wɑz flæt. "æn bɹeɪk ðə waɪt taʊɝ. əɡɛn, waɪ? jə kleɪm tə oʊbeɪ, əweɪt, ən sɝv, bʌt ðɪs ɪz ə læn ʌv oʊθ-bɹeɪkɝz. waɪ dʒju ɡɪv jəɹ læn tə mi? juv səm pɹaɪvət kwɔɹəl wɪð ðiz . . . wɪmən?"

"I am to sound it." Turak's tone was flat. "And break the White Tower. Again, why? You claim to obey, await, and serve, but this is a land of oath-breakers. Why do you give your land to me? Do you have some private quarrel with these . . . women?"

feɪn tʃɹaɪd tə meɪk ɪz vɔɪs kənvɪnsɪŋ. peɪʃənt, laɪk ə wɝm bɔɹɪŋ fɹəm wɪðɪn. "haɪ lɔɹd, maɪ fæmli hæz pæs daʊn ə tʃɹədɪʃən, dʒɛnɝeɪʃən əpɑn dʒɛnɝeɪʃən. wi sɝv ðə haɪ kɪŋ, ɑɹɾɝ pɛndʒɹæɡ tænɹəl, ən wən i wɑz mɝɾɝd baɪ ðə wɪtʃəz ə tɑɹ vəlɑn, wi dɪd nɑɾ əbændən əɹ oʊðz. wən ʌðɝz wɔɹɾ ən tɔɹ əpɑɹt wʌɾ ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ hæd meɪd, wi hɛl tə əɹ swɛɹɪŋ, ən sʌfɝd fəɹ ɪt, bʌt hɛl tə ɪt stɪl. ðɪs ɪz əɹ tʃɹədɪʃən, haɪ lɔɹd, hændəd fɑðɝ tə sʌn, ən mʌðɝ tə dɔɾɝ, daʊn ɔl ðə jɪɹz sɪns ðə haɪ kɪŋ wɑz mɝɾɝd. ðət wi əweɪt ðə ɹɪtɝn ə ði ɑɹmiz ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ sɛn əkɹɔs ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən, ðət wi əweɪt ðə ɹɪtɝn ʌv ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz blʌd tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðə waɪt taʊɝ ən teɪk bæk wʌt wɑz ðə haɪ kɪŋz. ən wən ðə hɔkwɪŋz blʌd ɹɪtɝnz, wɪl sɝv ən ædvaɪz, əz wi dɪd fəɹ ðə haɪ kɪŋ. haɪ lɔɹd, ɪksɛp fəɹ ɪts bɔɹɾɝ, ðə bænɝ ðət flaɪz oʊvɝ ðɪs ɹuf ɪz ðə bænɝ ə luthɛɹ, ðə sʌn ɑɹɾɝ pɛndʒɹæɡ tænɹəl sɛnt wɪð ɪz ɑɹmiz əkɹɔs ði oʊʃən." feɪn dʒɹɑp tə hɪz niz, ɡɪvɪŋ ə ɡʊɾ ɪməteɪʃən ə biɪŋ oʊvɝwɛlmd. "haɪ lɔɹd, aɪ wɪʃ oʊnli tə sɝv ən ædvaɪz ðə blʌɾ ə ðə haɪ kɪŋ."

Fain tried to make his voice convincing. Patient, like a worm boring from within. "High Lord, my family has passed down a tradition, generation upon generation. We served the High King, Artur Paendrag Tanreall, and when he was murdered by the witches of Tar Valon, we did not abandon our oaths. When others warred and tore apart what Artur Hawkwing had made, we held to our swearing, and suffered for it, but held to it still. This is our tradition, High Lord, handed father to son, and mother to daughter, down all the years since the High King was murdered. That we await the return of the armies Artur Hawkwing sent across the Aryth Ocean, that we await the return of Artur Hawkwing's blood to destroy the White Tower and take back what was the High King's. And when the Hawkwing's blood returns, we will serve and advise, as we did for the High King. High Lord, except for its border, the banner that flies over this roof is the banner of Luthair, the son Artur Paendrag Tanreall sent with his armies across the ocean." Fain dropped to his knees, giving a good imitation of being overwhelmed. "High Lord, I wish only to serve and advise the blood of the High King."

tʃɹɑk wɑz saɪlən soʊ lɔŋ ðət feɪn bɪɡæn tə wʌndɝ ɪf i niɾəd fɝðɝ kənvɪnsɪŋ; hi wɑz ɹɛɾi wɪð mɔɹ, əz mʌtʃ əz wɑz ɹikwaɪɝd. faɪnəli, ðoʊ, ðə haɪ lɔɹd spoʊk. "ju sim tə noʊ wʌt nʌn, niðɝ ðə haɪ nɔɹ ðə loʊ, hæz spoʊkən sɪns saɪɾɪŋ ðɪs lænd. ðə pipəl hɪɹ spik ɪɾ əz wʌn ɹumɝ əmʌŋ tɛn, bʌt jə noʊ. aɪ kən si ɪɾ ɪn jəɹ aɪz, hɪɹ ɪɾ ɪn jəɹ vɔɪs. aɪ kəɾ ɔlmoʊs θɪŋk jə wɝ sɛn tə ɛntæŋɡəl mi ɪn ə tʃɹæp. bʌt hu, pəzɛsɪŋ ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ, wəd juz ɪt soʊ? nʌn ə ðoʊz ə ðə blʌɾ u keɪm wɪð ðə heɪlin cʊɾə hæd ðə hɔɹn, fəɹ ðə lɛdʒən sɛz ɪt wɑz hɪɾən ɪn ðɪs lænd. ən ʃʊɹli ɛni lɔɹɾ ə ðɪs lænd wəd juz ɪɾ əɡɛns mi ɹæðɝ ðən pʊɾ ɪɾ ɪn maɪ hænz. haʊ dɪd jə kʌm tə pəzɛs ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ? dʒju kleɪm tə bi ə hɪɹoʊ, əz ɪn ðə lɛdʒənd? hæv jə dʌn vælɝəs didz?"

Turak was silent so long that Fain began to wonder if he needed further convincing; he was ready with more, as much as was required. Finally, though, the High Lord spoke. "You seem to know what none, neither the high nor the low, has spoken since sighting this land. The people here speak it as one rumor among ten, but you know. I can see it in your eyes, hear it in your voice. I could almost think you were sent to entangle me in a trap. But who, possessing the Horn of Valere, would use it so? None of those of the Blood who came with the Hailene could have had the Horn, for the legend says it was hidden in this land. And surely any lord of this land would use it against me rather than put it in my hands. How did you come to possess the Horn of Valere? Do you claim to be a hero, as in the legend? Have you done valorous deeds?"

"aɪ æm noʊ hɪɹoʊ, haɪ lɔɹd." feɪn vɛntʃɝɾ ə sɛlf-dɛpɹəkeɪɾɪŋ smaɪl, bʌt tʃɹɑks feɪs dɪd nɑɾ ɔltɝ, ən i lɛɾ ɪt ɡoʊ. "ðə hɔɹn wɑz faʊn baɪ ən ænsɛstɝ ə maɪn dʊɹɪŋ ðə tɝmɔɪl æftɝ ðə haɪ kɪŋz dɛθ. hi nu haʊ tə oʊpən ðə tʃɛst, bʌt ðət sikɹət daɪd wɪð ɪm ɪn ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz, ðət ɹɛn ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz ɛmpaɪɝ, soʊ ðəɾ ɔl wi hu fɑloʊɾ ɪm nu wɑz ðət ðə hɔɹn leɪ wɪðɪn ən wi mʌs kip ɪt seɪf əntɪl ðə haɪ kɪŋz blʌd ɹɪtɝnd."

"I am no hero, High Lord." Fain ventured a self-deprecating smile, but Turak's face did not alter, and he let it go. "The Horn was found by an ancestor of mine during the turmoil after the High King's death. He knew how to open the chest, but that secret died with him in the War of the Hundred Years, that rent Artur Hawkwing's empire, so that all we who followed him knew was that the Horn lay within and we must keep it safe until the High King's blood returned."

"ɔlmoʊs kəɾ aɪ bɪliv ju."

"Almost could I believe you."

"bɪliv, haɪ lɔɹd. wʌns jə saʊn ðə hɔɹn - "

"Believe, High Lord. Once you sound the Horn - "

"du nɑt ɹuən wʌt kənvɪnsɪŋ juv mænədʒ tə du. aɪ ʃæl nɑt saʊn ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ. wən aɪ ɹɪtɝn tə sintʃæn, aɪ ʃæl pɹɛzən ɪt tə ði ɛmpɹɛs əz ðə tʃifɛst ə maɪ tʃɹoʊfiz. pɝhæps ði ɛmpɹɛs wɪl saʊn ɪt hɝsɛlf."

"Do not ruin what convincing you have managed to do. I shall not sound the Horn of Valere. When I return to Seanchan, I shall present it to the Empress as the chiefest of my trophies. Perhaps the Empress will sound it herself."

"bʌt, haɪ lɔɹd," feɪn pɹətɛstəd, "ju mʌst - " hi faʊn hɪmsɛlf laɪɪŋ ɑn ɪz saɪd, hɪz hɛd ɹɪŋɪŋ. oʊnli wən ɪz aɪz klɪɹd dɪɾ i si ðə mæn wɪð ðə peɪl bɹeɪd ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz nʌkəlz ən ɹilaɪz wʌt hæd hæpənd.

"But, High Lord," Fain protested, "you must - " He found himself lying on his side, his head ringing. Only when his eyes cleared did he see the man with the pale braid rubbing his knuckles and realize what had happened.

"sʌm wɝdz," ðə fɛloʊ sɛd sɔfli, "ɑɹ nɛvɝ juz tə ðə haɪ lɔɹd."

"Some words," the fellow said softly, "are never used to the High Lord."

feɪn dɪsaɪɾɪd haʊ ðə mæn wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə daɪ.

Fain decided how the man was going to die.

tʃɹɑk lʊk fɹəm feɪn tə ðə hɔɹn əz plɑtʃədli əz ɪf i hæd sin nʌθɪŋ. "pɝhæps əl ɡɪv jə tə ði ɛmpɹɛs əlɔŋ wɪð ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ. ʃi maɪt faɪn jə əmjuzɪŋ, ə mæn u kleɪmz ɪz fæmli hɛl tʃɹu wɛɹ ɔl ʌðɝz bɹoʊk ðɛɹ oʊðz əɹ fɝɡɑt ðɛm."

Turak looked from Fain to the Horn as placidly as if he had seen nothing. "Perhaps I will give you to the Empress along with the Horn of Valere. She might find you amusing, a man who claims his family held true where all others broke their oaths or forgot them."

feɪn hɪɾ ɪz sʌɾən ɪleɪʃən ɪn ði ækt ə klaɪmɪŋ bæk tə hɪz fit. hi hæd nɑɾ ivən noʊn ə ði ɛɡzɪstəns ʌv ən ɛmpɹɛs əntɪl tʃɹɑk mɛnʃən hɝ, bʌɾ æksɛs tə ə ɹulɝ əɡɛn . . . ðəɾ oʊpənd nu pæðz, nu plænz. æksɛs tə ə ɹulɝ wɪð ðə maɪɾ ə ðə sintʃæn bɪniθ əɹ ən ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ ɪn əɹ hænz. mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ ðən meɪkɪŋ ðɪs tʃɹɑk ə ɡɹeɪt kɪŋ. hi kəd weɪt fəɹ səm pɑɹts ə hɪz plæn. sɔfli. mʌsnt lɛɾ ɪm noʊ haʊ mʌtʃ jə wɑn ɪt. æftɝ soʊ lɔŋ, ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ peɪʃəns wɪl nɑt hɝt. "æz ðə haɪ lɔɹd wɪʃɪz," hi sɛd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə saʊn laɪk ə mæn u oʊnli wɑntəd tə sɝv.

Fain hid his sudden elation in the act of climbing back to his feet. He had not even known of the existence of an Empress until Turak mentioned her, but access to a ruler again . . . that opened new paths, new plans. Access to a ruler with the might of the Seanchan beneath her and the Horn of Valere in her hands. Much better than making this Turak a Great King. He could wait for some parts of his plan. Softly. Mustn't let him know how much you want it. After so long, a little more patience will not hurt. "As the High Lord wishes," he said, trying to sound like a man who only wanted to serve.

"ju sim ɔlmoʊst iɡɝ," tʃɹɑk sɛd, ən feɪn bɛɹli səpɹɛst ə wɪns. "aɪ wɪl tɛl jə waɪ əl nɑt saʊn ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ, əɹ ivən kip ɪt, ən pɝhæps ðət wɪl kjʊɹ jəɹ iɡɝnəs. aɪ də nɑt wɪʃ ə ɡɪft ə maɪn tə əfɛn ði ɛmpɹɛs baɪ hɪz ækʃənz; ɪf jəɹ iɡɝnəs kænɑt bi kjʊɹd, ɪɾəl nɛvɝ bi sæɾəsfaɪd, fəɹ jəl nɛvɝ liv ðiz ʃɔɹz. dʒju noʊ ðət huɛvɝ bloʊz ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ ɪz lɪŋk tə ɪt ðɛɹæftɝ? ðət soʊ lɔŋ əz i əɹ ʃi lɪvz, ɪts noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə hɔɹn tə ɛni ʌðɝ?" hi dɪd nɑt saʊn əz ɪf i ɪkspɛktəɾ ænsɝz, ən ɪn ɛni keɪs, hi dɪd nɑt pɔz fəɹ ðɛm. "aɪ stæn twɛlfθ ɪn laɪn ə səksɛʃən tə ðə kɹɪstəl θɹoʊn. ɪf aɪ kɛp ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ, ɔl bɪtwin maɪsɛlf ən ðə θɹoʊn wəd θɪŋk aɪ mɛn tə bi fɝs hɪɹæftɝ, ən waɪl ði ɛmpɹɛs, ʌv kɔɹs, wɪʃɪz ðət wi kəntɛnd wɪð wʌn ənʌðɝ soʊ ðət ðə stʃɹɔŋɡəst ən moʊs kʌnɪŋ wɪl fɑloʊ hɝ, ʃi kɝənli feɪvɝz əɹ sɛkən dɔɾɝ, ən ʃi wəd nɑt lʊk wɛl ɑn ɛni θɹɛt tə tuɑn. ɪf aɪ saʊndəɾ ɪt, ivən ɪf aɪ ðən leɪd ðɪs læn əɾ əɹ fit, ən ɛvɹi wʊmən ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ liʃt, ði ɛmpɹɛs, meɪ ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ, wəd ʃʊɹli bɪliv aɪ mɛn tə bi mɔɹ ðən mɪɹli hɝ ɛɹ."

"You seem almost eager," Turak said, and Fain barely suppressed a wince. "I will tell you why I will not sound the Horn of Valere, or even keep it, and perhaps that will cure your eagerness. I do not wish a gift of mine to offend the Empress by his actions; if your eagerness cannot be cured, it will never be satisfied, for you will never leave these shores. Do you know that whoever blows the Horn of Valere is linked to it thereafter? That so long as he or she lives, it is no more than a horn to any other?" He did not sound as if he expected answers, and in any case, he did not pause for them. "I stand twelfth in line of succession to the Crystal Throne. If I kept the Horn of Valere, all between myself and the throne would think I meant to be first hereafter, and while the Empress, of course, wishes that we contend with one another so that the strongest and most cunning will follow her, she currently favors her second daughter, and she would not look well on any threat to Tuon. If I sounded it, even if I then laid this land at her feet, and every woman in the White Tower leashed, the Empress, may she live forever, would surely believe I meant to be more than merely her heir."

feɪn stɑp hɪmsɛlf ʃɔɹɾ ə sədʒɛstɪŋ haʊ pɑsəbəl ðət wəd bi wɪð ði eɪɾ ə ðə hɔɹn. sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ðə haɪ lɔɹdz vɔɪs sədʒɛstəd - əz hɑɹɾ əz feɪn faʊn ɪt tə bɪliv - ðəɾ i æktʃəli  mɛn ɪz wɪʃ fəɹ əɹ tə lɪv fɝɛvɝ. aɪ mʌs bi peɪʃənt. ə wɝm ɪn ðə ɹut.

Fain stopped himself short of suggesting how possible that would be with the aid of the Horn. Something in the High Lord's voice suggested - as hard as Fain found it to believe - that he actually meant his wish for her to live forever. I must be patient. A worm in the root.

"ði ɛmpɹɛsəz lɪsənɝz meɪ bi ɛniwɛɹ," tʃɹɑk kəntɪnjud. "ðeɪ meɪ bi ɛniwʌn. hwɑn wɑz bɔɹn ən ɹeɪzd ɪn ðə haʊs ʌv ələdɑn, ən ɪz fæmli fəɹ ɪlɛvən dʒɛnɝeɪʃənz bɪfɔɹ hɪm, jɛɾ ivən i kəd bi ə lɪsənɝ." ðə mæn wɪð ðə bɹeɪd hæf meɪɾ ə pɹətɛstɪŋ dʒɛstʃɝ, bɪfɔɹ dʒɝkɪŋ hɪmsɛlf bæk tə stɪlnəs. "ivən ə haɪ lɔɹɾ əɹ ə haɪ leɪɾi kən faɪn ðɛɹ dipəst sikɹəts noʊn tə lɪsənɝz, kən weɪk tə faɪn ðɛmsɛlvz ɔlɹɛɾi hændəɾ oʊvɝ tə ðə sikɝz fəɹ tʃɹuθ. tʃɹuθ ɪz ɔlweɪz dɪfəkəl tə faɪnd, bʌt ðə sikɝz spɛɹ noʊ peɪn ɪn ðɛɹ sɝtʃ, ən ðəl sɝtʃ əz lɔŋ əz ðeɪ θɪŋk ðəɹ ɪz nid. ðeɪ meɪk ɡɹeɪɾ ɛfɝts nɑt tə əlaʊ ə haɪ lɔɹɾ əɹ haɪ leɪɾi tə daɪ ɪn ðɛɹ kɛɹ, ʌv kɔɹs, fəɹ noʊ mænz hæn meɪ sleɪ wʌn ɪn huz veɪnz floʊz ðə blʌɾ ʌv ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ. ɪf ði ɛmpɹɛs mʌst ɔɹɾɝ sətʃ ə dɛθ, ði ənfɔɹtʃənət wʌn ɪz pleɪst əlaɪv ɪn ə sɪlkən bæɡ, ən ðət bæɡ hʌŋ oʊvɝ ðə saɪɾ ə ðə taʊɝ ə ðə ɹeɪvənz ən lɛf ðəɹ əntɪl ɪt ɹɑts əweɪ. noʊ sətʃ kɛɹ wəd bi teɪkən fəɹ wʌn sətʃ əz ju. ət ðə kɔɹɾ ə ðə naɪn munz, ɪn sindɑɹ, wʌn sətʃ əz jə kəd bi ɡɪvən tə ðə sikɝz fəɹ ə ʃɪft ə jəɹ aɪ, fəɹ ə mɪsspoʊkən wɝd, fəɹ ə wɪm. ɑɹ jə stɪl iɡɝ?"

"The Empress's Listeners may be anywhere," Turak continued. "They may be anyone. Huan was born and raised in the House of Aladon, and his family for eleven generations before him, yet even he could be a Listener." The man with the braid half made a protesting gesture, before jerking himself back to stillness. "Even a high lord or a high lady can find their deepest secrets known to Listeners, can wake to find themselves already handed over to the Seekers for Truth. Truth is always difficult to find, but the Seekers spare no pain in their search, and they will search as long as they think there is need. They make great efforts not to allow a high lord or high lady to die in their care, of course, for no man's hand may slay one in whose veins flows the blood of Artur Hawkwing. If the Empress must order such a death, the unfortunate one is placed alive in a silken bag, and that bag hung over the side of the Tower of the Ravens and left there until it rots away. No such care would be taken for one such as you. At the Court of the Nine Moons, in Seandar, one such as you could be given to the Seekers for a shift of your eye, for a misspoken word, for a whim. Are you still eager?"

feɪn mænədʒd ə tʃɹɛmbəl ɪn ɪz niz. "aɪ wɪʃ oʊnli tə sɝv ən ædvaɪz, haɪ lɔɹd. aɪ noʊ mʌtʃ ðət meɪ bi jusfəl." ðɪs kɔɹɾ ə sindɑɹ saʊndəɾ ə pleɪs wɛɹ ɪz plænz ən skɪlz wəd faɪn fɝɾəl sɔɪl.

Fain managed a tremble in his knees. "I wish only to serve and advise, High Lord. I know much that may be useful." This court of Seandar sounded a place where his plans and skills would find fertile soil.

"əntɪl aɪ seɪl bæk tə sintʃæn, jəl əmjuz mi wɪð jəɹ teɪlz ə jəɹ fæmli ən ɪts tʃɹədɪʃən. ɪts ə ɹɪlif tə faɪn ə sɛkən mæn ɪn ðɪs laɪt-fɔɹseɪkən læn u kən əmjuz mi, ivən ɪf jə boʊθ tɛl laɪz, əz aɪ səspɛkt. jə meɪ liv mi." noʊ ʌðɝ wɝd wɑz spoʊkən, bʌt ðə ɡɝl wɪð ðə nɪɹli waɪt hɛɹ ən ði ɔlmoʊst-tʃɹænspɛɹən ɹoʊb əpɪɹɾ ɑn kwɪk fit tə nil wɪð daʊnkæs hɛd bɪsaɪd ðə haɪ lɔɹd, ɔfɝɪŋ ə sɪŋɡəl stimɪŋ kʌp ɑn ə lækɝd tʃɹeɪ.

"Until I sail back to Seanchan, you will amuse me with your tales of your family and its tradition. It is a relief to find a second man in this Light-forsaken land who can amuse me, even if you both tell lies, as I suspect. You may leave me." No other word was spoken, but the girl with the nearly white hair and the almost-transparent robe appeared on quick feet to kneel with downcast head beside the High Lord, offering a single steaming cup on a lacquered tray.

"haɪ lɔɹd," feɪn sɛd. ðə mæn wɪð ðə bɹeɪd, hwɑn, tʊk hoʊld ə hɪz ɑɹm, bʌɾ i pʊld lus. hwɑnz maʊθ taɪɾənd æŋɡɹəli əz feɪn meɪɾ ɪz dipəs baʊ jɛt. əl kɪl ɪm sloʊli, jɛs. "haɪ lɔɹd, ðəɹ ɑɹ ðoʊz u fɑloʊ mi. ðeɪ min tə teɪk ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ. dɑɹkfɹɛnz ən wɝs, haɪ lɔɹd, ən ðeɪ kænɑt bi mɔɹ ðən ə deɪ əɹ tu bɪhaɪn mi."

"High Lord," Fain said. The man with the braid, Huan, took hold of his arm, but he pulled loose. Huan's mouth tightened angrily as Fain made his deepest bow yet. I will kill him slowly, yes. "High Lord, there are those who follow me. They mean to take the Horn of Valere. Darkfriends and worse, High Lord, and they cannot be more than a day or two behind me."

tʃɹɑk tʊk ə sɪp ə blæk lɪkwəd fɹəm ðə θɪn kʌp bælənst ɑn lɔŋ-neɪl fɪŋɡɝtɪps. "fju dɑɹkfɹɛnz ɹɪmeɪn ɪn sintʃæn. ðoʊz u sɝvaɪv ðə sikɝz fəɹ tʃɹuθ mit ði æks ə ðə hɛdzmən. ɪt maɪt bi əmjuzɪŋ tə miɾ ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd."

Turak took a sip of black liquid from the thin cup balanced on long-nailed fingertips. "Few Darkfriends remain in Seanchan. Those who survive the Seekers for Truth meet the axe of the headsman. It might be amusing to meet a Darkfriend."

"haɪ lɔɹd, ðeɪ ɑɹ deɪnʒɝəs. ðeɪv tʃɹɑləks wɪð ðɛm. ðeɪ ɑɹ lɛd baɪ wʌn u kɔlz hɪmsɛlf ɹænd ælθɹ. ə jʌŋ mæn, bʌt vaɪl ɪn ðə ʃædoʊ bɪɑn bɪlif, wɪð ə laɪɪŋ, diviəs tʌŋ. ɪn mɛni pleɪsəz hiz kleɪm tə bi mɛni θɪŋz, bʌɾ ɔlweɪz ðə tʃɹɑləks kʌm wən hiz ðɛɹ, haɪ lɔɹd. ɔlweɪz ðə tʃɹɑləks kʌm . . . ən kɪl."

"High Lord, they are dangerous. They have Trollocs with them. They are led by one who calls himself Rand al'Thor. A young man, but vile in the Shadow beyond belief, with a lying, devious tongue. In many places he has claimed to be many things, but always the Trollocs come when he is there, High Lord. Always the Trollocs come . . . and kill."

"tʃɹɑləks," tʃɹɑk mjuzd. "ðɛɹ wɝ noʊ tʃɹɑləks ɪn sintʃæn. bʌt ði ɑɹmiz ə ðə naɪt hæɾ ʌðɝ ælaɪz. ʌðɝ θɪŋz. aɪ hæv ɔfən wʌndɝɾ ɪf ə ɡɹoʊm kəd kɪl ə tʃɹɑlɑk. əl əv wɑtʃ kɛp fəɹ jəɹ tʃɹɑləks ən jəɹ dɑɹkfɹɛnz, ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹ nɑɾ ənʌðɝ laɪ. ðɪs lænd wɪɹiz mi wɪð bɔɹɾəm." hi saɪɾ ən ɪnheɪl ðə fjumz fɹəm ɪz kʌp.

"Trollocs," Turak mused. "There were no Trollocs in Seanchan. But the Armies of the Night had other allies. Other things. I have often wondered if a grolm could kill a Trolloc. I will have watch kept for your Trollocs and your Darkfriends, if they are not another lie. This land wearies me with boredom." He sighed and inhaled the fumes from his cup.

feɪn lɛt ðə ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ hwɑn pʊl ɪm aʊɾ ə ðə ɹum, hɑɹdli ivən lɪsnɪŋ tə ðə snɑɹəld lɛktʃɝ ɑn wʌt wəd hæpən ɪf i ɛvɝ əɡɛn feɪl tə liv lɔɹd tʃɹɑks pɹɛzəns wən ɡɪvən pɝmɪʃən tə də soʊ. hi bɛɹli noʊɾəst wən i wɑz pʊʃt ɪndə ðə stʃɹit wɪð ə kɔɪn ən ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz tə ɹɪtɝn ɑn ðə mɑɹoʊ. ɹænd ælθɹ wɑz hɪz, naʊ. əl si hɪm dɛɾ ət læst. ən ðən ðə wɝld wɪl peɪ fəɹ wʌt wɑz dʌn tə mi.

Fain let the grimacing Huan pull him out of the room, hardly even listening to the snarled lecture on what would happen if he ever again failed to leave Lord Turak's presence when given permission to do so. He barely noticed when he was pushed into the street with a coin and instructions to return on the morrow. Rand al'Thor was his, now. I will see him dead at last. And then the world will pay for what was done to me.

ɡɪɡəlɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ, hi lɛɾ ɪz hɔɹsəz daʊn ɪndə ðə taʊn ɪn sɝtʃ ʌv ən ɪn.

Giggling under his breath, he led his horses down into the town in search of an inn.


tʃæptɝ θɝɾifaɪv


CHAPTER 35

stɛɾɪŋ tsəfu


Stedding Tsofu

ðə ɹɪvɝ hɪlz ɑn wɪtʃ ðə sɪɾi ʌv kɛɹhin stʊd ɡeɪv weɪ tə flæɾɝ lænz ən fɔɹəsts wən ɹænd ən ði ʌðɝz hæd ɹɪɾən hæf ə deɪ, ðə ʃaɪnɝənz stɪl wɪð ðɛɹ ɑɹmɝ ɑn ðə pækhɔɹsɪz. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ ɹoʊdz wɛɹ ðeɪ wɛnt, oʊnli ə skæɾɝɪŋ ə kɑɹt tʃɹæks, ən fju fɑɹmz əɹ vɪlədʒəz. vɛɹɪn pɹɛs fəɹ spid, ən ɪŋtʃɹ - ɡɹʌmbəlɪŋ kɑnstənli ðət ðeɪ wɝ lɛɾɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz bi tʃɹɪkt, ðət feɪn wəd nɛvɝ əv toʊld əm wɛɹ i wɑz ɹɪli ɡoʊɪŋ, jɛt ɡɹʌmbəlɪŋ ət ðə seɪm taɪm əbaʊt ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪn ði ɑpəzət dɝɛkʃən fɹəm toʊmən hɛd, əz ɪf pɑɹɾ ə hɪm bɪlivd ən toʊmən hɛd wɝ nɑt mʌnθs əweɪ ɪksɛp baɪ ðə weɪ ðeɪ tʊk - ɪŋtʃɹ əblaɪdʒ hɝ. ðə ɡɹeɪ aʊl bænɝ flu ɑn ðə wɪn ə ðɛɹ pæsədʒ.

The river hills on which the city of Cairhien stood gave way to flatter lands and forests when Rand and the others had ridden half a day, the Shienarans still with their armor on the packhorses. There were no roads where they went, only a scattering of cart tracks, and few farms or villages. Verin pressed for speed, and Ingtar - grumbling constantly that they were letting themselves be tricked, that Fain would never have told them where he was really going, yet grumbling at the same time about riding in the opposite direction from Toman Head, as if part of him believed and Toman Head were not months away except by the way they took - Ingtar obliged her. The Gray Owl banner flew on the wind of their passage.

ɹænd ɹoʊd wɪð ɡɹɪm dɪtɝməneɪʃən, əvɔɪɾɪŋ kɑnvɝseɪʃən wɪð vɛɹɪn. hi hæd ðɪs θɪŋ tə də - ðɪs duɾi, ɪŋtʃɹ wʊɾə kɔld ɪt - ən ðən i kəd bi fɹi ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ wʌns ən fəɹ ɔl. pɛɹɪn sim tə ʃɛɹ sʌmθɪŋ ə hɪz mud, stɛɹɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛɾ ət nʌθɪŋ əz ðeɪ ɹoʊd. wən ðeɪ faɪnəli stɑp fəɹ ðə naɪɾ ət ði ɛdʒ ʌv ə fɔɹəst, wɪð fʊl dɑɹk ɔlmoʊst ɑn ðɛm, pɛɹɪn æsk lɔɪəl kwɛstʃənz əbaʊt ðə stɛɾɪŋ. tʃɹɑləks wəd nɑɾ ɛntɝ ə stɛɾɪŋ; wəd wʊlvz? lɔɪəl ɹɪplaɪd ʃɔɹtli ðəɾ ɪt wɑz oʊnli kɹitʃɝz ə ðə ʃædoʊ ðət wɝ ɹɪlʌktən tə ɛntɝ stɛɾɪŋ. ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, ʌv kɔɹs, sɪns ðeɪ kəd nɑt tʌtʃ ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs ɪnsaɪɾ ə stɛɾɪŋ, əɹ tʃænəl ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ði oʊɡiɝ hɪmsɛlf əpɪɹd ðə moʊst ɹɪlʌktən ʌv ɔl tə ɡoʊ tə stɛɾɪŋ tsəfu. mæt wɑz ði oʊnli wʌn u simd iɡɝ, ɔlmoʊs dɛspɝətli soʊ. hɪz skɪn lʊkt əz ɪf i hæd nɑt sin ðə sʌn ɪn ə jɪɹ, ən ɪz tʃiks hæd bɪɡʌn tə ɡoʊ hɑloʊ, ðoʊ hi sɛɾ i fɛlt ɹɛɾi tə ɹʌn ə fʊtʃɹeɪs. vɛɹɪn pʊɾ əɹ hænz ɑn ɪm fəɹ hilɪŋ bɪfɔɹ i ɹoʊld ɪndə hɪz blæŋkəts, ən əɡɛn bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ maʊntəd ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪt meɪd noʊ dɪfɝəns ɪn haʊ hi lʊkt. ivən hʊɹɪn fɹaʊnd wən i lʊkt ət mæt.

Rand rode with grim determination, avoiding conversation with Verin. He had this thing to do - this duty, Ingtar would have called it - and then he could be free of Aes Sedai once and for all. Perrin seemed to share something of his mood, staring straight ahead at nothing as they rode. When they finally stopped for the night at the edge of a forest, with full dark almost on them, Perrin asked Loial questions about the stedding. Trollocs would not enter a stedding; would wolves? Loial replied shortly that it was only creatures of the Shadow that were reluctant to enter stedding. And Aes Sedai, of course, since they could not touch the True Source inside a stedding, or channel the One Power. The Ogier himself appeared the most reluctant of all to go to Stedding Tsofu. Mat was the only one who seemed eager, almost desperately so. His skin looked as if he had not seen the sun in a year, and his cheeks had begun to go hollow, though he said he felt ready to run a footrace. Verin put her hands on him for Healing before he rolled into his blankets, and again before they mounted their horses in the morning, but it made no difference in how he looked. Even Hurin frowned when he looked at Mat.

ðə sʌn stʊd haɪ ɑn ðə sɛkən deɪ wən vɛɹɪn sʌɾənli sæɾ ʌp stʃɹeɪɾ ɪn əɹ sæɾəl ən lʊkt ɝaʊnd. bɪsaɪd hɝ, ɪŋtʃɹ ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt.

The sun stood high on the second day when Verin suddenly sat up straight in her saddle and looked around. Beside her, Ingtar gave a start.

ɹænd kəd nɑt si ɛniθɪŋ dɪfɹən əbaʊt ðə fɔɹəs naʊ sɝaʊndɪŋ ðɛm. ði ʌndɝɡɹoʊθ wɑz nɑt tu θɪk; ðeɪ hæd faʊn ən izi weɪ ʌndɝ ðə kænəpi ʌv oʊk ən hɪkɝi, blækɡəm ən bitʃ, pɪɹs hɪɹ ən ðəɹ baɪ ə tɔl paɪn əɹ lɛðɝlif, əɹ ðə waɪt slæʃ ʌv ə peɪpɝbɑɹk. bʌɾ əz i fɑloʊd ðɛm, hi sʌɾənli fɛlt ə tʃɪl pæs θɹu hɪm, əz ðoʊ hi hæd lɛpt ɪndə ə wɔɾɝwʊd pɑn ɪn wɪntɝ. ɪt flæʃt θɹu hɪm ən wɑz ɡɔn, livɪŋ bɪhaɪn ə filɪŋ ə ɹəfɹɛʃmənt. ən ðəɹ wɑz ə dʌl ən dɪstən sɛns ə lɔs, tu, ðoʊ hi kəd nɑɾ ɪmædʒən ʌv wʌt.

Rand could not see anything different about the forest now surrounding them. The undergrowth was not too thick; they had found an easy way under the canopy of oak and hickory, blackgum and beech, pierced here and there by a tall pine or leatherleaf, or the white slash of a paperbark. But as he followed them, he suddenly felt a chill pass through him, as though he had leaped into a Waterwood pond in winter. It flashed through him and was gone, leaving behind a feeling of refreshment. And there was a dull and distant sense of loss, too, though he could not imagine of what.

ɛvɹi ɹaɪɾɝ, əz i ɹitʃt ðət pɔɪnt, ɡeɪv ə dʒɝk əɹ meɪd səm ɛkskləmeɪʃən. hʊɹɪnz maʊθ dʒɹɑpt oʊpən, ən ənoʊ wɪspɝd, "blʌɾi, fleɪmɪŋ. . . ." ðən i ʃʊk ɪz hɛɾ əz ɪf i kəd nɑt θɪŋk ʌv ɛniθɪŋ ɛls tə seɪ. ðəɹ wɑz ə lʊk ə ɹɛkəɡnɪʃən ɪn pɛɹɪnz jɛloʊ aɪz.

Every rider, as he reached that point, gave a jerk or made some exclamation. Hurin's mouth dropped open, and Uno whispered, "Bloody, flaming. . . ." Then he shook his head as if he could not think of anything else to say. There was a look of recognition in Perrin's yellow eyes.

lɔɪəl tʊk ə dip, sloʊ bɹɛθ ən lɛɾ ɪɾ aʊt. "ɪt filz . . . ɡʊd . . . tə bi bæk ɪn ə stɛɾɪŋ."

Loial took a deep, slow breath and let it out. "It feels . . . good . . . to be back in a stedding."

fɹaʊnɪŋ, ɹænd lʊkt ɝaʊnd. hi hæɾ ɪkspɛktəɾ ə stɛɾɪŋ tə bi sʌmhaʊ dɪfɹənt, bʌɾ ɪksɛp fəɹ ðət wʌn tʃɪl, ðə fɔɹəst wɑz ðə seɪm əz wʌt ðeɪ hæd bɪn ɹaɪɾɪŋ θɹu ɔl deɪ. ðəɹ wɑz ðə sʌɾən sɛns ə biɪŋ ɹɛstəd, ʌv kɔɹs. ðən ən oʊɡiɝ stɛpt aʊt fɹəm bɪhaɪn ən oʊk.

Frowning, Rand looked around. He had expected a stedding to be somehow different, but except for that one chill, the forest was the same as what they had been riding through all day. There was the sudden sense of being rested, of course. Then an Ogier stepped out from behind an oak.

ʃi wɑz ʃɔɹɾɝ ðən lɔɪəl - wɪtʃ mɛnt ʃi stʊd hɛɾ ən ʃoʊldɝz tɔlɝ ðən ɹænd - bʌt wɪð ðə seɪm bɹɔd noʊz ən bɪɡ aɪz, ðə seɪm waɪd maʊθ ən tʌftəɾ ɪɹz. hɝ aɪbɹaʊz wɝ nɑt soʊ lɔŋ əz lɔɪəlz, ðoʊ, ən əɹ fitʃɝz sim dɛləkət bɪsaɪd hɪz, ðə tʌfs ɑn əɹ ɪɹz faɪnɝ. ʃi wɔɹ ə lɔŋ ɡɹin dʒɹɛs ən ə ɡɹin kloʊk ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð flaʊɝz, ən kæɹiɾ ə bʌntʃ ə sɪlvɝbɛl blɑsəmz əz ɪf ʃi hæd bɪn ɡæðɝɪŋ ðɛm. ʃi lʊkt əɾ əm kɑmli, weɪɾɪŋ.

She was shorter than Loial - which meant she stood head and shoulders taller than Rand - but with the same broad nose and big eyes, the same wide mouth and tufted ears. Her eyebrows were not so long as Loial's, though, and her features seemed delicate beside his, the tufts on her ears finer. She wore a long green dress and a green cloak embroidered with flowers, and carried a bunch of silverbell blossoms as if she had been gathering them. She looked at them calmly, waiting.

lɔɪəl skɹæmbəl daʊn fɹəm ɪz tɔl hɔɹs ən baʊd heɪstəli. ɹænd ən ði ʌðɝz dɪd ðə seɪm, ɪf nɑt soʊ kwɪkli əz lɔɪəl; ivən vɛɹɪn ɪnklaɪn əɹ hɛd. lɔɪəl ɡeɪv ðɛɹ neɪmz fɔɹməli, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt mɛnʃən ðə neɪm ə hɪz stɛɾɪŋ.

Loial scrambled down from his tall horse and bowed hastily. Rand and the others did the same, if not so quickly as Loial; even Verin inclined her head. Loial gave their names formally, but he did not mention the name of his stedding.

fəɹ ə moʊmən ði oʊɡiɝ ɡɝl - ɹænd wɑz ʃʊɹ ʃi wɑz noʊ oʊldɝ ðən lɔɪəl - stʌɾid ðɛm, ðən smaɪld. "bi wɛlkəm tə stɛɾɪŋ tsəfu." hɝ vɔɪs wɑz ə laɪɾɝ vɝʒən ə lɔɪəlz, tu; ðə sɑftɝ ɹʌmbəl ʌv ə smɔlɝ bʌmbəlɪbi. "aɪ æm ɛɹɪθ, dɔɾɝ ʌv ivə dɔɾɝ ʌv eɪlɑɹ. bi wɛlkəm. wɪv hæd soʊ fju hjumən vɪzəɾɝz sɪns ðə stoʊnmeɪsɑnz lɛf kɛɹhin, ən naʊ soʊ mɛni ət wʌns. waɪ, wi ivən hæd səm ə ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ pipəl, ðoʊ, ʌv kɔɹs, ðeɪ lɛft wən ðə. . . . oʊ, aɪ tɔk tu mʌtʃ. əl teɪk jə tə ði ɛldɝz. oʊnli. . . ." ʃi sɝtʃt əmʌŋ əm fəɹ ðə wʌn ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ, ən sɛɾəld faɪnəli ɑn vɛɹɪn. "ɛɛs sədaɪ, juv soʊ mɛni mɛn wɪð ju, ən ɑɹmd. kəd jə pliz liv səm ə ðɛm aʊtsaɪd? fɝɡɪv mi, bʌɾ ɪts ɔlweɪz ənsɛɾəlɪŋ tə hæv vɛɹi mɛni ɑɹm hjumənz ɪn ðə stɛɾɪŋ ət wʌns."

For a moment the Ogier girl - Rand was sure she was no older than Loial - studied them, then smiled. "Be welcome to Stedding Tsofu." Her voice was a lighter version of Loial's, too; the softer rumble of a smaller bumblebee. "I am Erith, daughter of Iva daughter of Alar. Be welcome. We have had so few human visitors since the stonemasons left Cairhien, and now so many at once. Why, we even had some of the Traveling People, though, of course, they left when the. . . . Oh, I talk too much. I will take you to the Elders. Only. . . ." She searched among them for the one in charge, and settled finally on Verin. "Aes Sedai, you have so many men with you, and armed. Could you please leave some of them Outside? Forgive me, but it is always unsettling to have very many armed humans in the stedding at once."

"ʌv kɔɹs, ɛɹɪθ," vɛɹɪn sɛd. "ɪŋtʃɹ, wɪl jə si tə ɪt?"

"Of course, Erith," Verin said. "Ingtar, will you see to it?"

ɪŋtʃɹ ɡeɪv ɔɹɾɝz tə ənoʊ, ən soʊ ɪt wɑz ðəɾ i ən hʊɹɪn wɝ ði oʊnli ʃaɪnɝənz tə fɑloʊ ɛɹɪθ dipɝ ɪndə ðə stɛɾɪŋ.

Ingtar gave orders to Uno, and so it was that he and Hurin were the only Shienarans to follow Erith deeper into the stedding.

liɾɪŋ ɪz hɔɹs laɪk ði ʌðɝz, ɹænd lʊkt ʌp əz lɔɪəl keɪm kloʊsɝ, wɪð mɛni ɡlænsɪz əɾ ɛɹɪθ ʌp əhɛd wɪð vɛɹɪn ən ɪŋtʃɹ. hʊɹɪn wɔk mɪdweɪ bɪtwin, stɛɹɪŋ ɝaʊn ɪn əmeɪzmənt, ðoʊ ɹænd wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ət wʌɾ ɪɡzækli. lɔɪəl bɛn tə spik kwaɪətli. "ɪz ʃi nɑt bjuɾəfəl, ɹænd? ən əɹ vɔɪs sɪŋz."

Leading his horse like the others, Rand looked up as Loial came closer, with many glances at Erith up ahead with Verin and Ingtar. Hurin walked midway between, staring around in amazement, though Rand was not sure at what exactly. Loial bent to speak quietly. "Is she not beautiful, Rand? And her voice sings."

mæt snɪkɝd, bʌt wən lɔɪəl lʊkt əɾ ɪm kwɛstʃənɪŋli, hi sɛd, "vɛɹi pɹɪɾi, lɔɪəl. ə lɪɾəl tɔl fəɹ maɪ teɪst, jə ʌndɝstænd, bʌt vɛɹi pɹɪɾi, aɪm ʃʊɹ."

Mat snickered, but when Loial looked at him questioningly, he said, "Very pretty, Loial. A little tall for my taste, you understand, but very pretty, I'm sure."

lɔɪəl fɹaʊn ənsɝteɪnli, bʌt nɑɾəd. "jɛs, ʃi ɪz." hɪz ɪkspɹɛʃən laɪɾənd. "ɪt dʌz fil ɡʊd tə bi bæk ɪn ə stɛɾɪŋ. nɑt ðət ðə lɔŋɪŋ wɑz teɪkɪŋ mi, jə ʌndɝstænd."

Loial frowned uncertainly, but nodded. "Yes, she is." His expression lightened. "It does feel good to be back in a stedding. Not that the Longing was taking me, you understand."

"ðə lɔŋɪŋ?" pɛɹɪn sɛd. "aɪ də nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd, lɔɪəl."

"The Longing?" Perrin said. "I do not understand, Loial."

"wi oʊɡiɝ ɑɹ baʊn tə ðə stɛɾɪŋ, pɛɹɪn. ɪts sɛd ðət bɪfɔɹ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld, wi kəd ɡoʊ wɛɹ wi wɪʃt fəɹ əz lɔŋ əz wi wɪʃt, laɪk jə hjumənz, bʌt ðət tʃeɪnʒd wɪð ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ. oʊɡiɝ wɝ skæɾɝd laɪk ɛvɹi ʌðɝ pipəl, ən ðeɪ kəd nɑt faɪn ɛni ʌv ðə stɛɾɪŋ əɡɛn. ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɑz muvd, ɛvɹiθɪŋ tʃeɪnʒd. maʊntənz, ɹɪvɝz, ivən ðə siz."

"We Ogier are bound to the stedding, Perrin. It is said that before the Breaking of the World, we could go where we wished for as long as we wished, like you humans, but that changed with the Breaking. Ogier were scattered like every other people, and they could not find any of the stedding again. Everything was moved, everything changed. Mountains, rivers, even the seas."

"ɛvɹibɑɾi noʊz əbaʊt ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ," mæt sɛɾ ɪmpeɪʃənli. "wʌt dʌz ɪɾ əv tə də wɪð ðɪs - ðɪs lɔŋɪŋ?"

"Everybody knows about the Breaking," Mat said impatiently. "What does it have to do with this - this Longing?"

"ɪt wɑz dʊɹɪŋ ði ɛɡzaɪl, waɪl wi wɑndɝd lɔst, ðət ðə lɔŋɪŋ fɝs keɪm ɑn ʌs. ðə dɪzaɪɝ tə noʊ ðə stɛɾɪŋ wʌns mɔɹ, tə noʊ əɹ hoʊmz əɡɛn. mɛni daɪɾ ʌv ɪt." lɔɪəl ʃʊk ɪz hɛd sædli. "mɔɹ daɪd ðən lɪvd. wən wi faɪnəli bɪɡæn tə faɪn ðə stɛɾɪŋ əɡɛn, wʌn əɾ ə taɪm, ɪn ðə jɪɹz ə ðə kʌvənən ə ðə tɛn neɪʃənz, ɪt simd wi hæd dɪfiɾəd ðə lɔŋɪŋ ət læst, bʌɾ ɪt hæd tʃeɪnʒd ʌs, pʊt sidz ɪn ʌs. naʊ, ɪf ən oʊɡiɝ ɪz aʊtsaɪd tu lɔŋ, ðə lɔŋɪŋ kʌmz əɡɛn; hi bɪɡɪnz tə wikən, ən i daɪz ɪf i dʌz nɑt ɹɪtɝn."

"It was during the Exile, while we wandered lost, that the Longing first came on us. The desire to know the stedding once more, to know our homes again. Many died of it." Loial shook his head sadly. "More died than lived. When we finally began to find the stedding again, one at a time, in the years of the Covenant of the Ten Nations, it seemed we had defeated the Longing at last, but it had changed us, put seeds in us. Now, if an Ogier is Outside too long, the Longing comes again; he begins to weaken, and he dies if he does not return."

"du jə nid tə steɪ hɪɹ əwaɪl?" ɹænd æskt æŋkʃəsli. "ðɛɹz noʊ nid tə kɪl jɝsɛlf tə ɡoʊ wɪð ʌs."

"Do you need to stay here awhile?" Rand asked anxiously. "There's no need to kill yourself to go with us."

"aɪ wɪl noʊ ɪt wən ɪt kʌmz." lɔɪəl læft. "ɪt wɪl bi lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ɪts stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə kɑz hɑɹm tə mi. waɪ, dælɝ spɛn tɛn jɪɹz əmʌŋ ðə si foʊk wɪθaʊɾ ɛvɝ siɪŋ ə stɛɾɪŋ, ən ʃi keɪm seɪfli hoʊm."

"I will know it when it comes." Loial laughed. "It will be long before it is strong enough to cause harm to me. Why, Dalar spent ten years among the Sea Folk without ever seeing a stedding, and she came safely home."

ən oʊɡiɝ wʊmən əpɪɹɾ aʊɾ ə ðə tʃɹiz, pɔzɪŋ ə moʊmən tə spik wɪð ɛɹɪθ ən vɛɹɪn. ʃi lʊkt ɪŋtʃɹ ʌp ən daʊn ən sim tə dɪsmɪs hɪm, wɪtʃ meɪɾ ɪm blɪŋk. hɝ aɪz swɛpt əkɹɔs lɔɪəl, flɪkt oʊvɝ hʊɹɪn ən ði ɛmənz fildɝz, bɪfɔɹ ʃi wɛn ɔf ɪndə ðə fɔɹəst əɡɛn; lɔɪəl sim tə bi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə haɪd bɪhaɪn ɪz hɔɹs. "bɪsaɪdz," hi sɛd, piɹɪŋ kɔʃəsli əkɹɔs ɪz sæɾəl æftɝ hɝ, "ɪɾ ɪz ə dʌl laɪf ɪn ðə stɛɾɪŋ kəmpɛɹd tə tʃɹævlɪŋ wɪð θɹi tɑvɝən."

An Ogier woman appeared out of the trees, pausing a moment to speak with Erith and Verin. She looked Ingtar up and down and seemed to dismiss him, which made him blink. Her eyes swept across Loial, flicked over Hurin and the Emond's Fielders, before she went off into the forest again; Loial seemed to be trying to hide behind his horse. "Besides," he said, peering cautiously across his saddle after her, "it is a dull life in the stedding compared to traveling with three ta'veren."

"ɪf jə ɑɹ gɑnə stɑɹt ðəɾ əɡɛn," mæt mʌɾɝd, ən lɔɪəl spoʊk ʌp kwɪkli. "θɹi fɹɛnz, ðɛn. jə ɑɹ maɪ fɹɛnz, aɪ hoʊp."

"If you are going to start that again," Mat muttered, and Loial spoke up quickly. "Three friends, then. You are my friends, I hope."

"aɪ æm," ɹænd sɛd sɪmpli, ən pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd.

"I am," Rand said simply, and Perrin nodded.

mæt læft. "haʊ kəɾ aɪ nɑt bi fɹɛnz wɪð sʌmbɑɾi hu daɪsɪz soʊ bædli?" hi θɹu ʌp ɪz hænz wən ɹænd ən pɛɹɪn lʊkt ət hɪm. "oʊ, ɔl ɹaɪt. aɪ laɪk ju, lɔɪəl. jəɹ maɪ fɹɛnd. dʒʌs doʊnt ɡoʊ ɑn əbaʊt. . . . ɑ! səmtaɪmz jəɹ əz bæd tə bi ɝaʊn əz ɹænd." hɪz vɔɪs sæŋk tə ə mʌɾɝ. "æt list wɝ seɪf hɪɹ ɪn ə stɛɾɪŋ."

Mat laughed. "How could I not be friends with somebody who dices so badly?" He threw up his hands when Rand and Perrin looked at him. "Oh, all right. I like you, Loial. You're my friend. Just don't go on about. . . . Aaah! Sometimes you're as bad to be around as Rand." His voice sank to a mutter. "At least we're safe here in a stedding."

ɹænd ɡɹɪməst. hi nu wʌt mæt mɛnt. hɪɹ ɪn ə stɛɾɪŋ, wɛɹ aɪ kæn tʃænəl.

Rand grimaced. He knew what Mat meant. Here in a stedding, where I can't channel.

pɛɹɪn pʌntʃt mæts ʃoʊldɝ, bʌt lʊk sɑɹi ðəɾ i hæd wən mæt ɡɹɪməst əɾ ɪm wɪð ðət ɡɔn feɪs.

Perrin punched Mat's shoulder, but looked sorry that he had when Mat grimaced at him with that gaunt face.

ɪt wɑz ðə mjuzɪk ɹænd bɪkeɪm əwɛɹ ə fɝst, ənsin fluts ən fɪɾəlz ɪn ə dʒɑli tun ðət floʊɾəd θɹu ðə tʃɹiz, ən dip vɔɪsəz sɪŋɪŋ ən læfɪŋ.

It was the music Rand became aware of first, unseen flutes and fiddles in a jolly tune that floated through the trees, and deep voices singing and laughing.

"klɪɹ ðə fild, smuð ɪt loʊ.

"Clear the field, smooth it low.

lɛt noʊ wiɾ əɹ stʌbəl stænd.

Let no weed or stubble stand.

hɪɹ wi leɪbɝ, hɪɹ wi tɔɪl, hɪɹ ðə taʊɝɪŋ tʃɹiz wɪl ɡɹoʊ."

Here we labor, here we toil, here the towering trees will grow."

ɔlmoʊst ət ðə seɪm moʊmən i ɹilaɪz ðət ðə hjudʒ ʃeɪp i wɑz siɪŋ θɹu ðə tʃɹiz wɑz ɪtsɛlf ə tʃɹi, wɪð ə ɹɪdʒd, bʌtʃɹəs tʃɹʌŋk ðət mʌst əv bɪn twɛnti peɪsɪz θɪk. ɡeɪpɪŋ, hi fɑloʊɾ ɪɾ ʌp wɪð ɪz aɪz, ʌp θɹu ðə fɔɹəs kænəpi, tə bɹæntʃəz spɹɛɾɪŋ laɪk ðə tɑp ʌv ə dʒaɪɡæntɪk mʌʃɹum ə ɡʊd hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz əbʌv ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ən bɪɑn ɪt wɝ tɔlɝ stɪl.

Almost at the same moment he realized that the huge shape he was seeing through the trees was itself a tree, with a ridged, buttressed trunk that must have been twenty paces thick. Gaping, he followed it up with his eyes, up through the forest canopy, to branches spreading like the top of a gigantic mushroom a good hundred paces above the ground. And beyond it were taller still.

"bɝn mi," mæt bɹiðd. "ju kəd bɪl tɛn haʊsəz fɹəm dʒʌst wʌn ə ðoʊz. fɪfti haʊsəz."

"Burn me," Mat breathed. "You could build ten houses from just one of those. Fifty houses."

"kʌt daʊn ə ɡɹeɪt tʃɹi?" lɔɪəl saʊndəd skændəlaɪzd, ən mɔɹ ðən ə lɪɾəl æŋɡɹi. hɪz ɪɹz wɝ stɪf ən stɪl, hɪz lɔŋ aɪbɹaʊz daʊn ɑn ɪz tʃiks. "wi nɛvɝ kʌt daʊn wʌn ə ðə ɡɹeɪt tʃɹiz, nɑɾ ənlɛs ɪt daɪz, ən ðeɪ ɔlmoʊs nɛvɝ du. fju sɝvaɪv ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ, bʌt səm ə ðə lɑɹdʒəst wɝ sidlɪŋz dʊɹɪŋ ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz."

"Cut down a Great Tree?" Loial sounded scandalized, and more than a little angry. His ears were stiff and still, his long eyebrows down on his cheeks. "We never cut down one of the Great Trees, not unless it dies, and they almost never do. Few survived the Breaking, but some of the largest were seedlings during the Age of Legends."

"aɪm sɑɹi," mæt sɛd. "aɪ wɑz dʒʌst seɪɪŋ haʊ bɪɡ ðeɪ ɑɹ. aɪ woʊn hɝt jəɹ tʃɹiz." lɔɪəl nɑɾəd, simɪŋ mɑləfaɪd.

"I'm sorry," Mat said. "I was just saying how big they are. I won't hurt your trees." Loial nodded, seeming mollified.

mɔɹ oʊɡiɝ əpɪɹd naʊ, wɔkɪŋ əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz. moʊst simd ɪntɛn ɑn wʌtɛvɝ ðeɪ wɝ əbaʊt; ðoʊ ɔl lʊkt ət ðə nukʌmɝz, ən ivən ɡeɪv ə fɹɛnli nɑɾ əɹ ə smɔl baʊ, nʌn stɑpt əɹ spoʊk. ðeɪ hæɾ ə kjʊɹiəs weɪ ʌv muvɪŋ, ɪn səm mænɝ blɛndɪŋ ə kɛɹfəl dɪlɪbɝætnəs wɪð ən ɔlmoʊs tʃaɪldlaɪk kɛɹfɹi dʒɔɪfəlnəs. ðeɪ nu ən laɪkt u ən wʌt ðeɪ wɝ ən wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ, ən ðeɪ simd ət pis wɪð ðɛmsɛlvz ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɝaʊn ðɛm. ɹænd faʊn hɪmsɛlf ɛnviɪŋ ðɛm.

More Ogier appeared now, walking among the trees. Most seemed intent on whatever they were about; though all looked at the newcomers, and even gave a friendly nod or a small bow, none stopped or spoke. They had a curious way of moving, in some manner blending a careful deliberateness with an almost childlike carefree joyfulness. They knew and liked who and what they were and where they were, and they seemed at peace with themselves and everything around them. Rand found himself envying them.

fju ʌv ði oʊɡiɝ mɛn wɝ ɛni tɔlɝ ðən lɔɪəl, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz izi tə pɪk aʊt ði oʊldɝ mɛn; wʌn ən ɔl ðeɪ wɔɹ mʌstæʃɪz əz lɔŋ əz ðɛɹ dæŋɡəlɪŋ aɪbɹaʊz ən nɛɹoʊ bɪɹdz ʌndɝ ðɛɹ tʃɪnz. ɔl ə ðə jʌŋɡɝ wɝ smuð-ʃeɪvən, laɪk lɔɪəl. mɛni ʌv ðə mɛn wɝ ɪn ðɛɹ ʃɝtslivz, ən kæɹid ʃʌvəlz ən mæɾəks əɹ sɔz ən bʌkəts ə pɪtʃ; ði ʌðɝz wɔɹ pleɪn koʊts ðət bʌɾənd tə ðə nɛk ən flɛɹɾ əbaʊt ðɛɹ niz laɪk kɪls. ðə wɪmən sim tə feɪvɝ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd flaʊɝz, ən mɛni wɔɹ flaʊɝz ɪn ðɛɹ hɛɹ, tu. ði ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi wɑz lɪməɾəd tə ðə kloʊks ə ðə jʌŋɡɝ wɪmən; ði oʊldɝ wɪmənz dʒɹɛsəz wɝ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd, əz wɛl, ən səm wɪmən wɪð ɡɹeɪ hɛɹ hæd flaʊɝz ən vaɪnz fɹəm nɛk tə hɛm. ə hændfʊl ə ði oʊɡiɝ, wɪmən ən ɡɝlz fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt, dɪd sim tə teɪk spɛʃəl noʊɾəs ə lɔɪəl; hi wɔk stɛɹɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛd, ɪɹz twɪtʃɪŋ mɔɹ waɪldli ðə fɝðɝ ðeɪ wɛnt.

Few of the Ogier men were any taller than Loial, but it was easy to pick out the older men; one and all they wore mustaches as long as their dangling eyebrows and narrow beards under their chins. All of the younger were smooth-shaven, like Loial. Many of the men were in their shirtsleeves, and carried shovels and mattocks or saws and buckets of pitch; the others wore plain coats that buttoned to the neck and flared about their knees like kilts. The women seemed to favor embroidered flowers, and many wore flowers in their hair, too. The embroidery was limited to the cloaks of the younger women; the older women's dresses were embroidered, as well, and some women with gray hair had flowers and vines from neck to hem. A handful of the Ogier, women and girls for the most part, did seem to take special notice of Loial; he walked staring straight ahead, ears twitching more wildly the further they went.

ɹænd wɑz stɑɹɾəld tə si ən oʊɡiɝ əpɛɹənli wɔkɪŋ ʌp aʊɾ ə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, aʊɾ ʌv wʌn ə ðə ɡɹæsi, waɪldflaʊɝ-kʌvɝd maʊnz ðət leɪ skæɾɝd ɔl əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz hɪɹ. ðən i sɔ wɪndoʊz ɪn ðə maʊnz, ən ən oʊɡiɝ wʊmən stændɪŋ ət wʌn əpɛɹənli ɹoʊlɪŋ ə pikɹʌst, ən ɹilaɪzd i wɑz lʊkɪŋ əɾ oʊɡiɝ haʊzɪz. ðə wɪndoʊ fɹeɪmz wɝ stoʊn, bʌt ðeɪ nɑɾ oʊnli sim nætʃɹəl fɔɹmeɪʃənz, ðeɪ əpɪɹd tə hæv bɪn skʌlptɪd baɪ wɪn ən wɔɾɝ oʊvɝ dʒɛnɝeɪʃənz.

Rand was startled to see an Ogier apparently walking up out of the ground, out of one of the grassy, wildflower-covered mounds that lay scattered all among the trees here. Then he saw windows in the mounds, and an Ogier woman standing at one apparently rolling a piecrust, and realized he was looking at Ogier houses. The window frames were stone, but they not only seemed natural formations, they appeared to have been sculpted by wind and water over generations.

ðə ɡɹeɪt tʃɹiz, wɪð ðɛɹ mæsɪv tʃɹʌŋks ən spɹɛɾɪŋ ɹuts əz θɪk əz hɔɹsəz, niɾəd ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə ɹum bɪtwin ðɛm, bʌt sɛvɹəl ɡɹu ɹaɪɾ ɪn ðə taʊn. dɝt ɹæmps tʊk ðə pæðz oʊvɝ ðə ɹuts. ɪn fækt, əsaɪd fɹəm ðə pæθweɪz, ði oʊnli weɪ tə tɛl taʊn fɹəm fɔɹəst əɾ ə ɡlæns wɑz ə lɑɹdʒ oʊpən speɪs ɪn ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə taʊn, ɝaʊnd wʌt kəɾ oʊnli bi ðə stʌmp ʌv wʌn ə ðə ɡɹeɪt tʃɹiz. nɪɹli ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz əkɹɔs, ɪts sɝfəs wɑz pɑlɪʃt əz smuð əz ɛni flɔɹ, ən ðəɹ wɝ stɛps bɪlt ʌp tə ɪɾ ət sɛvɹəl pleɪsəz. ɹænd wɑz ɪmædʒənɪŋ haʊ tɔl ðət tʃɹi hæd bɪn wən ɛɹɪθ spoʊk laʊdli ɪnʌf fəɹ əm ɔl tə hɪɹ.

The Great Trees, with their massive trunks and spreading roots as thick as horses, needed a great deal of room between them, but several grew right in the town. Dirt ramps took the paths over the roots. In fact, aside from the pathways, the only way to tell town from forest at a glance was a large open space in the center of the town, around what could only be the stump of one of the Great Trees. Nearly a hundred paces across, its surface was polished as smooth as any floor, and there were steps built up to it at several places. Rand was imagining how tall that tree had been when Erith spoke loudly enough for them all to hear.

"hɪɹ kʌm əɹ ʌðɝ ɡɛsts."

"Here come our other guests."

θɹi hjumən wɪmən keɪm wɔkɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə saɪɾ ə ðə hjudʒ stʌmp. ðə jʌŋɡəst wɑz kæɹiɪŋ ə wʊɾən boʊl.

Three human women came walking around the side of the huge stump. The youngest was carrying a wooden bowl.

"il," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd. "meɪɾənz ə ðə spɪɹ. əz wɛl aɪ dɪd liv mæsimə wɪð ði ʌðɝz." jɛɾ i stɛpt əweɪ fɹəm vɛɹɪn ən ɛɹɪθ, ən ɹitʃt oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ tə lusən ɪz sɔɹɾ ɪn ɪts skæbɝd.

"Aiel," Ingtar said. "Maidens of the Spear. As well I did leave Masema with the others." Yet he stepped away from Verin and Erith, and reached over his shoulder to loosen his sword in its scabbard.

ɹænd stʌɾid ði il wɪð ən ənizi kjʊɹiɑsəɾi. ðeɪ wɝ wʌt tu mɛni pipəl hæd tʃɹaɪd tə tɛl ɪm i wɑz. tu ʌv ðə wɪmən wɝ mətʃʊɹ, ði ʌðɝ lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən ə ɡɝl, bʌɾ ɔl θɹi wɝ tɔl fəɹ wɪmən. ðɛɹ ʃɔɹt-kʌt hɛɹ ɹeɪnʒd fɹəm ə ɹɛɾɪʃ bɹaʊn tə ɔlmoʊst ɡoʊldən, wɪð ə nɛɹoʊ, ʃoʊldɝ-lɛŋθ teɪl lɛf lɔŋ ət ðə bæk. ðeɪ wɔɹ lus bɹitʃɪz tʌkt ɪndə sɑf buts, ən ɔl ðɛɹ kloʊðz wɝ səm ʃeɪɾ ə bɹaʊn əɹ ɡɹeɪ əɹ ɡɹin; hi θɔt ðə ɡɑɹməns wəd feɪɾ ɪndə ɹɑk əɹ wʊdz ɔlmoʊst əz wɛl əz ə wɔɹɾɝz kloʊk. ʃɔɹt baʊz poʊkt oʊvɝ ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz, kwɪvɝz ən lɔŋ naɪvz hʌŋ ət ðɛɹ bɛls, ən itʃ kæɹiɾ ə smɔl, ɹaʊnd ʃild ə haɪɾ ən ə klʌstɝ ə spɪɹz wɪð ʃɔɹt ʃæfs ən lɔŋ pɔɪns. ivən ðə jʌŋɡəs muvd wɪð ə ɡɹeɪs ðət sədʒɛstəd ʃi nu haʊ tə juz ðə wɛpənz ʃi kæɹid.

Rand studied the Aiel with an uneasy curiosity. They were what too many people had tried to tell him he was. Two of the women were mature, the other little more than a girl, but all three were tall for women. Their short-cut hair ranged from a reddish brown to almost golden, with a narrow, shoulder-length tail left long at the back. They wore loose breeches tucked into soft boots, and all their clothes were some shade of brown or gray or green; he thought the garments would fade into rock or woods almost as well as a Warder's cloak. Short bows poked over their shoulders, quivers and long knives hung at their belts, and each carried a small, round shield of hide and a cluster of spears with short shafts and long points. Even the youngest moved with a grace that suggested she knew how to use the weapons she carried.

əbɹʌpli ðə wɪmən bɪkeɪm əwɛɹ ə ði ʌðɝ hjumənz; ðeɪ simd əz stɑɹɾəld ət biɪŋ stɑɹɾəld əz ðeɪ dɪɾ ət ðə saɪɾ ə ɹænd ən ði ʌðɝz, bʌt ðeɪ muv laɪk laɪtnɪŋ. ðə jʌŋɡəst wʌn ʃaʊɾəd, "ʃaɪnɝənz!" ən tɝn tə sɛt ðə boʊl kɛɹfəli bɪhaɪn hɝ. ði ʌðɝ tu kwɪkli lɪftəd bɹaʊn klɔθs fɹəm ɝaʊn ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz, ɹæpɪŋ əm ɝaʊn ðɛɹ hɛdz ɪnstɛd. ði oʊldɝ wɪmən wɝ ɹeɪzɪŋ blæk veɪlz əkɹɔs ðɛɹ feɪsəz, haɪɾɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ bʌt ðɛɹ aɪz, ən ðə jʌŋɡəst stʃɹeɪɾənd tə ɪməteɪt ðɛm. kɹaʊtʃɪŋ loʊ, ðeɪ ədvænst əɾ ə dɪlɪbɝɪt peɪs, ʃilz hɛl fɔɹwɝd wɪð ðɛɹ klʌstɝz ə spɪɹz, ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə wʌn itʃ wʊmən hɛld ɹɛɾi ɪn əɹ ʌðɝ hænd.

Abruptly the women became aware of the other humans; they seemed as startled at being startled as they did at the sight of Rand and the others, but they moved like lightning. The youngest one shouted, "Shienarans!" and turned to set the bowl carefully behind her. The other two quickly lifted brown cloths from around their shoulders, wrapping them around their heads instead. The older women were raising black veils across their faces, hiding everything but their eyes, and the youngest straightened to imitate them. Crouching low, they advanced at a deliberate pace, shields held forward with their clusters of spears, except for the one each woman held ready in her other hand.

ɪŋtʃɹz sɔɹd keɪm aʊɾ ʌv ɪts ʃiθ. "stæn klɪɹ, ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɛɹɪθ, stæn klɪɹ." hʊɹɪn snætʃt aʊɾ ɪz sɔɹd-bɹeɪkɝ, weɪvɝd bɪtwin kʌdʒəl ən sɔɹd fəɹ ɪz ʌðɝ hænd; æftɝ ənʌðɝ ɡlæns ət ði ilz spɪɹz, hi tʃoʊz ðə sɔɹd.

Ingtar's sword came out of its sheath. "Stand clear, Aes Sedai. Erith, stand clear." Hurin snatched out his sword-breaker, wavered between cudgel and sword for his other hand; after another glance at the Aiel's spears, he chose the sword.

"ju mʌs nɑt," ði oʊɡiɝ ɡɝl pɹətɛstəd. ɹɪŋɪŋ əɹ hænz, ʃi tɝn fɹəm ɪŋtʃɹ tə ði il ən bæk. "ju mʌs nɑt."

"You must not," the Ogier girl protested. Wringing her hands, she turned from Ingtar to the Aiel and back. "You must not."

ɹænd ɹilaɪz ðə hɛɹən-mɑɹk bleɪd wɑz ɪn ɪz hænz. pɛɹɪn hæɾ ɪz æks hæf aʊɾ ə ðə lup əɾ ɪz bɛlt ən wɑz hɛzəteɪɾɪŋ, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd.

Rand realized the heron-mark blade was in his hands. Perrin had his axe half out of the loop at his belt and was hesitating, shaking his head.

"ɑɹ jə tu kɹeɪzi?" mæt dɪmændəd. hɪz baʊ stɪl slæntəɾ əkɹɔs ɪz bæk. "aɪ doʊn kɛɹ ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹ il, ðəɹ wɪmən."

"Are you two crazy?" Mat demanded. His bow still slanted across his back. "I don't care if they are Aiel, they're women."

"stɑp ðɪs!" vɛɹɪn dɪmændəd. "stɑp ðɪs ɪmiɾiətli!" ði il nɛvɝ bɹoʊk stʃɹaɪd, ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ klɛntʃt əɹ fɪsts ɪn fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən.

"Stop this!" Verin demanded. "Stop this immediately!" The Aiel never broke stride, and the Aes Sedai clenched her fists in frustration.

mæt muv bæk tə pʊɾ ə fʊɾ ɪn ɪz stɝəp. "aɪm livɪŋ," hi ənaʊnst. "ju hɪɹ mi? aɪm nɑt steɪɪŋ tə lɛɾ əm stɪk ðoʊz θɪŋz ɪn mi, ən aɪm nɑt gɑnə ʃuɾ ə wʊmən!"

Mat moved back to put a foot in his stirrup. "I'm leaving," he announced. "You hear me? I'm not staying to let them stick those things in me, and I am not going to shoot a woman!"

"ðə pækt!" lɔɪəl wɑz ʃaʊɾɪŋ. "ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə pækt!" ɪt hæd noʊ mɔɹ ɪfɛk ðən ðə kəntɪnjud pliz fɹəm vɛɹɪn ən ɛɹɪθ.

"The Pact!" Loial was shouting. "Remember the Pact!" It had no more effect than the continued pleas from Verin and Erith.

ɹænd noʊɾəst ðət boʊθ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ði oʊɡiɝ ɡɝl wɝ kipɪŋ wɛl aʊɾ ə ði ilz weɪ. hi wʌndɝɾ ɪf mæt hæd ðə ɹaɪɾ aɪdiə. hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ i kəd hɝɾ ə wʊmən ivən ɪf ʃi wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kɪl hɪm. wʌt dɪsaɪɾɪd ɪm wɑz ðə θɔt ðəɾ ivən ɪf i dɪd mænədʒ tə ɹitʃ ɹɛdz sæɾəl, ði il wɝ naʊ noʊ mɔɹ ðən θɝɾi peɪsɪz əweɪ. hi səspɛktəd ðoʊz ʃɔɹt spɪɹz kəd bi θɹoʊn ðət fɑɹ. əz ðə wɪmən keɪm kloʊsɝ, stɪl kɹaʊtʃɪŋ, spɪɹz ɹɛɾi, hi stɑpt wɝiɪŋ əbaʊt nɑt hɝɾɪŋ əm ən bɪɡæn wɝiɪŋ əbaʊt haʊ tə stɑp əm fɹəm hɝɾɪŋ hɪm.

Rand noticed that both the Aes Sedai and the Ogier girl were keeping well out of the Aiel's way. He wondered if Mat had the right idea. He was not sure he could hurt a woman even if she was trying to kill him. What decided him was the thought that even if he did manage to reach Red's saddle, the Aiel were now no more than thirty paces away. He suspected those short spears could be thrown that far. As the women came closer, still crouching, spears ready, he stopped worrying about not hurting them and began worrying about how to stop them from hurting him.

nɝvəsli, hi sɔt ðə vɔɪd, ən ɪt keɪm. ən ðə dɪstən θɔt floʊɾəd aʊtsaɪɾ ɪt ðəɾ ɪt wɑz oʊnli ðə vɔɪd. ðə ɡloʊ ʌv seɪɾɪn wɑz nɑt ðɛɹ. ði ɛmptinəs wɑz mɔɹ ɛmpti ðən i ɛvɝ ɹɪmɛmbɝd, væstɝ, laɪk ə hʌŋɡɝ ɡɹeɪɾ ɪnʌf tə kənsum hɪm. ə hʌŋɡɝ fəɹ mɔɹ; ðəɹ wɑz səpoʊz tə bi sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ.

Nervously, he sought the void, and it came. And the distant thought floated outside it that it was only the void. The glow of saidin was not there. The emptiness was more empty than he ever remembered, vaster, like a hunger great enough to consume him. A hunger for more; there was supposed to be something more.

əbɹʌpli ən oʊɡiɝ stʃɹoʊɾ ɪn bɪtwin ðə tu ɡɹups, hɪz nɛɹoʊ bɪɹd kwɪvɝɪŋ. "wʌɾ ɪz ðə minɪŋ ə ðɪs? pʊɾ ʌp jəɹ wɛpənz." hi saʊndəd skændəlaɪzd. "fɔɹ ju" - hɪz ɡlɛɹ tʊk ɪn ɪŋtʃɹ ən hʊɹɪn, ɹænd ən pɛɹɪn, ən dɪd nɑt spɛɹ mæt fəɹ ɔl ɪz ɛmpti hænz - "ðɛɹ ɪz səm ɪkskjus, bʌt fəɹ jə - " hi ɹaʊndəɾ ɑn ði il wɪmən, hu hæd stɑp ðɛɹ ədvæns. "hæv jə fɝɡɑɾən ðə pækt?"

Abruptly an Ogier strode in between the two groups, his narrow beard quivering. "What is the meaning of this? Put up your weapons." He sounded scandalized. "For you" - his glare took in Ingtar and Hurin, Rand and Perrin, and did not spare Mat for all his empty hands - "there is some excuse, but for you - " He rounded on the Aiel women, who had stopped their advance. "Have you forgotten the Pact?"

ðə wɪmən ənkʌvɝd ðɛɹ hɛdz ən feɪsəz soʊ heɪstəli ðəɾ ɪt sim ðeɪ wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pɹitɛn ðeɪ hæd nɛvɝ bɪn kʌvɝd. ðə ɡɝlz feɪs wɑz bɹaɪt ɹɛd, ən ði ʌðɝ wɪmən lʊkt əbæʃt. wʌn ə ði oʊldɝ wɪmən, ðə wʌn wɪð ðə ɹɛɾɪʃ hɛɹ, sɛd, "fɝɡɪv ʌs, tʃɹibɹəðɝ. wi ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə pækt, ən wi wəd nɑɾ əv bɛɹd stil, bʌt wəɹ ɪn ðə læn ə ðə tʃɹikɪlɝz, wɛɹ ɛvɹi hæn ɪz əɡɛnst ʌs, ən wi sɔ ɑɹmd mɛn." hɝ aɪz wɝ ɡɹeɪ, ɹænd sɔ, laɪk ɪz oʊn.

The women uncovered their heads and faces so hastily that it seemed they were trying to pretend they had never been covered. The girl's face was bright red, and the other women looked abashed. One of the older women, the one with the reddish hair, said, "Forgive us, Treebrother. We remember the Pact, and we would not have bared steel, but we are in the land of the Treekillers, where every hand is against us, and we saw armed men." Her eyes were gray, Rand saw, like his own.

"ju ɑɹ ɪn ə stɛɾɪŋ, ɹiən," ði oʊɡiɝ sɛd dʒɛnli. "ɛvɹiwʌn ɪz seɪf ɪn ðə stɛɾɪŋ, lɪɾəl sɪstɝ. ðəɹ ɪz noʊ faɪɾɪŋ hɪɹ, ən noʊ hæn ɹeɪzd əɡɛnst ənʌðɝ." ʃi nɑɾəd, əʃeɪmd, ən ði oʊɡiɝ lʊkt əɾ ɪŋtʃɹ ən ði ʌðɝz.

"You are in a stedding, Rhian," the Ogier said gently. "Everyone is safe in the stedding, little sister. There is no fighting here, and no hand raised against another." She nodded, ashamed, and the Ogier looked at Ingtar and the others.

ɪŋtʃɹ ʃiðd ɪz sɔɹd, ən ɹænd dɪd ðə seɪm, ðoʊ nɑt soʊ kwɪkli əz hʊɹɪn, hu lʊkt ɔlmoʊst əz ɪmbɛɹəst əz ði il. pɛɹɪn hæd nɛvɝ ɡɑɾən ɪz æks ɔl ðə weɪ aʊt. əz i tʊk hæn fɹəm hɪlt, ɹænd lɛt ðə vɔɪd ɡoʊ, tu, ən ʃɪvɝd. ðə vɔɪd wɛnt, bʌɾ ɪt lɛf bɪhaɪn ə sloʊli feɪɾɪŋ ɛkoʊ ʌv ði ɛmptinəs ɔl θɹu hɪm, ən ə dɪzaɪɝ fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ tə fɪl ɪt.

Ingtar sheathed his sword, and Rand did the same, though not so quickly as Hurin, who looked almost as embarrassed as the Aiel. Perrin had never gotten his axe all the way out. As he took hand from hilt, Rand let the void go, too, and shivered. The void went, but it left behind a slowly fading echo of the emptiness all through him, and a desire for something to fill it.

ði oʊɡiɝ tɝn tə vɛɹɪn ən baʊd. "ɛɛs sədaɪ, aɪm dʒun, sʌn ə ləsəl sʌn ə lɔd. aɪ hæv kʌm tə teɪk jə tə ði ɛldɝz. ðeɪ wəd noʊ waɪ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ kʌmz əmʌŋ ʌs, wɪð ɑɹmd mɛn ən wʌn ʌv əɹ oʊn juðz." lɔɪəl hʌntʃt ɪz ʃoʊldɝz əz ɪf tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dɪsəpɪɹ.

The Ogier turned to Verin and bowed. "Aes Sedai, I am Juin, son of Lacel son of Laud. I have come to take you to the Elders. They would know why an Aes Sedai comes among us, with armed men and one of our own youths." Loial hunched his shoulders as if trying to disappear.

vɛɹɪn ɡeɪv ði il ə ɹɪɡɹɛtfəl lʊk, əz ɪf ʃi wɑntəd tə tɔk wɪð ðɛm, ðən moʊʃən dʒun tə lid, ən i tʊk əɹ əweɪ wɪθaʊɾ ənʌðɝ wɝɾ əɹ ivən ðə fɝs lʊk ət lɔɪəl.

Verin gave the Aiel a regretful look, as if she wanted to talk with them, then motioned Juin to lead, and he took her away without another word or even the first look at Loial.

fəɹ ə fju moʊməns, ɹænd ən ði ʌðɝz stʊd feɪsɪŋ ðə θɹi il wɪmən ənizəli. ət list, ɹænd nu hi wɑz ənizi. ɪŋtʃɹ sim stɛɾi əz ə stoʊn, wɪð noʊ mɔɹ ɪkspɹɛʃən ðən wʌn. ði il maɪɾ əv ənveɪl ðɛɹ feɪsəz, bʌt ðeɪ stɪl hæd spɪɹz ɪn ðɛɹ hænz, ən ðeɪ stʌɾid ðə fɔɹ mɛn əz ðoʊ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə si ɪnsaɪd ðɛm. ɹænd ɪn pɝtɪkjəlɝ ɹəsivd ɪnkɹisɪŋli æŋɡɹi lʊks. hi hɝd ðə jʌŋɡəst wʊmən mʌɾɝ, "hi ɪz wɛɹɪŋ ə sɔɹd," ɪn toʊnz ə mɪŋɡəl hɔɹɝ ən kəntɛmpt. ðən ðə θɹi wɝ livɪŋ, stɑpɪŋ tə ɹɪtʃɹiv ðə wʊɾən boʊl ən lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz ət ɹænd ən ði ʌðɝz əntɪl ðeɪ vænɪʃt əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz.

For a few moments, Rand and the others stood facing the three Aiel women uneasily. At least, Rand knew he was uneasy. Ingtar seemed steady as a stone, with no more expression than one. The Aiel might have unveiled their faces, but they still had spears in their hands, and they studied the four men as though trying to see inside them. Rand in particular received increasingly angry looks. He heard the youngest woman mutter, "He is wearing a sword," in tones of mingled horror and contempt. Then the three were leaving, stopping to retrieve the wooden bowl and looking over their shoulders at Rand and the others until they vanished among the trees.

"meɪɾənz ə ðə spɪɹ," ɪŋtʃɹ mʌɾɝd. "aɪ nɛvɝ θɔt ðeɪd stɑp wʌns ðeɪ veɪl ðɛɹ feɪsəz. sɝɾənli nɑt fəɹ ə fju wɝdz." hi lʊkt ət ɹænd ən ɪz tu fɹɛnz. "ju ʃəd si ə tʃɑɹdʒ baɪ ɹɛd ʃilz, əɹ stoʊn dɑɡz. əz izi tə stɑp əz ən ævəlæntʃ."

"Maidens of the Spear," Ingtar muttered. "I never thought they'd stop once they veiled their faces. Certainly not for a few words." He looked at Rand and his two friends. "You should see a charge by Red Shields, or Stone Dogs. As easy to stop as an avalanche."

"ðeɪ wəd nɑt bɹeɪk ðə pækt wʌns ɪt wɑz ɹɪkɔl tə ðɛm," ɛɹɪθ sɛd, smaɪlɪŋ. "ðeɪ keɪm fəɹ sʌŋ wʊd." ə noʊɾ ə pɹaɪɾ ɛntɝɾ əɹ vɔɪs. "wi hæv tu tʃɹisɪŋɝz ɪn stɛɾɪŋ tsəfu. ðeɪ ɑɹ ɹɛɹ, naʊ. aɪ hæv hɝd ðət stɛɾɪŋ ʃæŋktaɪ hæz ə jʌŋ tʃɹisɪŋʒɝ u ɪz vɛɹi tæləntəd, bʌt wɪv tu." lɔɪəl blʌʃt, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑɾ əpɪɹ tə noʊɾəs. "ɪf jəl kʌm wɪð mi, əl ʃoʊ jə wɛɹ jə meɪ weɪɾ əntɪl ði ɛldɝz əv spoʊkən."
