"They would not break the Pact once it was recalled to them," Erith said, smiling. "They came for sung wood." A note of pride entered her voice. "We have two Treesingers in Stedding Tsofu. They are rare, now. I have heard that Stedding Shangtai has a young Treesinger who is very talented, but we have two." Loial blushed, but she did not appear to notice. "If you will come with me, I will show you where you may wait until the Elders have spoken."

əz ðeɪ fɑloʊd hɝ, pɛɹɪn mɝmɝd, "sʌŋ wʊd, maɪ lɛft fʊt. ðoʊz il ɑɹ sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ i hu kʌmz wɪð ðə dɔn."

As they followed her, Perrin murmured, "Sung wood, my left foot. Those Aiel are searching for He Who Comes With the Dawn."

ən mæt æɾəd dʒɹaɪli, "ðeɪɹ lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ju, ɹænd."

And Mat added dryly, "They're looking for you, Rand."

"fɔɹ mi! ðəɾ ɪz kɹeɪzi. wʌt meɪks jə θɪŋk - "

"For me! That is crazy. What makes you think - "

hi kʌɾ ɔf əz ɛɹɪθ ʃoʊɾ əm daʊn ðə stɛps ʌv ə waɪldflaʊɝ-kʌvɝd haʊs əpɛɹənli sɛɾ əsaɪd fəɹ hjumən ɡɛsts. ðə ɹumz wɝ twɛnti peɪsɪz fɹəm stoʊn wɔl tə stoʊn wɔl, wɪð peɪntəd silɪŋz ə ɡʊd tu spænz əbʌv ðə flɔɹ, bʌt ði oʊɡiɝ hæd dʌn ðɛɹ bɛs meɪkɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ ðət wəd bi kʌmftəɹbəl fəɹ hjumənz. ivən soʊ, ðə fɝnɪtʃɝ wɑz ə lɪɾəl tu lɑɹdʒ fəɹ kʌmfɝt, ðə tʃɛɹz tɔl ɪnʌf tə lɪft ə mænz hilz ɔf ðə flɔɹ, ðə teɪbəl haɪɝ ðən ɹændz weɪst. hʊɹɪn, ət list, cʊɾə wɔkt ɪɹɛkt ɪndə ðə stoʊn faɪɝpleɪs, wɪtʃ sim tə hæv bɪn wɔɹn baɪ wɔɾɝ ɹæðɝ ðən meɪd baɪ hænz. ɛɹɪθ aɪd lɔɪəl daʊtfəli, bʌɾ i weɪvd əweɪ hɝ kənsɝn ən pʊld wʌn ə ðə tʃɛɹz ɪndə ðə kɔɹnɝ list izəli sin fɹəm ðə dɔɹ.

He cut off as Erith showed them down the steps of a wildflower-covered house apparently set aside for human guests. The rooms were twenty paces from stone wall to stone wall, with painted ceilings a good two spans above the floor, but the Ogier had done their best making something that would be comfortable for humans. Even so, the furniture was a little too large for comfort, the chairs tall enough to lift a man's heels off the floor, the table higher than Rand's waist. Hurin, at least, could have walked erect into the stone fireplace, which seemed to have been worn by water rather than made by hands. Erith eyed Loial doubtfully, but he waved away her concern and pulled one of the chairs into the corner least easily seen from the door.

əz sun əz ði oʊɡiɝ ɡɝl lɛft, ɹænd ɡɑt mæt ən pɛɹɪn oʊvɝ tə wʌn saɪd. "wʌt dʒju min ðəɹ lʊkɪŋ fəɹ mi? waɪ? fəɹ wʌt ɹizən? ðeɪ lʊkt ɹaɪɾ ət mi, ən wɛn əweɪ."

As soon as the Ogier girl left, Rand got Mat and Perrin over to one side. "What do you mean they're looking for me? Why? For what reason? They looked right at me, and went away."

"ðeɪ lʊkt ət ju," mæt sɛd wɪð ə ɡɹɪn, "laɪk jə hædn beɪðd ɪn ə mʌnθ, ən hæd daʊs jɝsɛlf wɪð ʃipdɪp bɪsaɪdz." hɪz ɡɹɪn feɪɾəd. "bʌt ðeɪ kəd bi lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ju. wi mɛɾ ənʌðɝ il."

"They looked at you," Mat said with a grin, "like you hadn't bathed in a month, and had doused yourself with sheepdip besides." His grin faded. "But they could be looking for you. We met another Aiel."

ɹænd lɪsən ɪn ɡɹoʊɪŋ əmeɪzmən tə ðɛɹ teɪl ə ðə miɾɪŋ ɪn kɪnsleɪɝz dæɡɝ. mæt toʊl moʊst ʌv ɪt, wɪð pɛɹɪn pʊɾɪŋ ɪn ə kɝɛktɪŋ wɝd naʊ ən əɡɛn wən i ɛmbɛlɪʃt tu mʌtʃ. mæt meɪɾ ə ɡɹeɪt ʃoʊ ʌv haʊ deɪnʒɝəs ði ilmən hæd bɪn, ən haʊ kloʊz ðə miɾɪŋ hæd kʌm tə ə faɪt.

Rand listened in growing amazement to their tale of the meeting in Kinslayer's Dagger. Mat told most of it, with Perrin putting in a correcting word now and again when he embellished too much. Mat made a great show of how dangerous the Aielman had been, and how close the meeting had come to a fight.

"æn sɪns jəɹ ði oʊnli il wi noʊ," hi fɪnɪʃt, "wɛl, ɪt kəd bi ju. ɪŋtʃɹ sɛz il nɛvɝ lɪv aʊtsaɪd ðə weɪst, soʊ jə mʌs bi ði oʊnli wʌn."

"And since you're the only Aiel we know," he finished, "well, it could be you. Ingtar says Aiel never live outside the Waste, so you must be the only one."

"aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðæts fʌni, mæt," ɹænd ɡɹaʊld. "aɪ æm nɑɾ ən il." ði æmɪɝlɪn sɛd jə ɑɹ. ɪŋtʃɹ θɪŋks jə ɑɹ. tæm sɛd. . . . hi wɑz sɪk, fivɝd. ðeɪ hæd sɛvɝd ðə ɹuts i hæd θɔɾ i hæd, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən tæm bɪtwin ðɛm, ðoʊ tæm hæd bɪn tu sɪk tə noʊ wʌɾ i wɑz seɪɪŋ. ðeɪ hæd kʌɾ ɪm lus tə tʌmbəl bɪfɔɹ ðə wɪnd, ðən ɔfɝɾ ɪm sʌmθɪŋ nu tə hoʊld ɑn tə. fɔls dʒɹæɡən. il. hi kəd nɑt kleɪm ðoʊz fəɹ ɹuts. hi wəd nɑt. "meɪbi aɪ doʊn bɪlɔŋ tə ɛniwʌn. bʌt ðə tu ɹɪvɝz ɪz ði oʊnli hoʊm aɪ noʊ."

"I don't think that's funny, Mat," Rand growled. "I am not an Aiel." The Amyrlin said you are. Ingtar thinks you are. Tam said. . . . He was sick, fevered. They had severed the roots he had thought he had, the Aes Sedai and Tam between them, though Tam had been too sick to know what he was saying. They had cut him loose to tumble before the wind, then offered him something new to hold on to. False Dragon. Aiel. He could not claim those for roots. He would not. "Maybe I don't belong to anyone. But the Two Rivers is the only home I know."

"aɪ dɪdn min ɛniθɪŋ," mæt pɹətɛstəd. "ɪts dʒʌst. . . . bɝn mi, ɪŋtʃɹ sɛz jə ɑɹ. mæsimə sɛz jə ɑɹ. jɝaɪn cʊɾə bɪn jəɹ kʌzən, ən ɪf ɹiən pʊɾ ɑn ə dʒɹɛs ən sɛd ʃi wɑz jəɹ ænt, jud bɪliv ɪt jɝsɛlf. oʊ, ɔl ɹaɪt. doʊn lʊk ət mi laɪk ðæt, pɛɹɪn. ɪf i wɑns tə seɪ hi ɪzənt, ɔl ɹaɪt. wʌt dɪfɝəns dʌz ɪt meɪk, ɛniweɪ?" pɛɹɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd.

"I didn't mean anything," Mat protested. "It's just. . . . Burn me, Ingtar says you are. Masema says you are. Urien could have been your cousin, and if Rhian put on a dress and said she was your aunt, you'd believe it yourself. Oh, all right. Don't look at me like that, Perrin. If he wants to say he isn't, all right. What difference does it make, anyway?" Perrin shook his head.

oʊɡiɝ ɡɝlz bɹɔt wɔɾɝ ən taʊəlz fəɹ wɑʃɪŋ feɪsəz ən hænz, ən tʃiz ən fɹuɾ ən waɪn, wɪð pjuɾɝ ɡoʊbləts ə lɪɾəl tu lɑɹdʒ tə bi kʌmftəɹbəl ɪn ðə hænd. ʌðɝ oʊɡiɝ wɪmən keɪm, tu, ðɛɹ dʒɹɛsəz ɔl ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd. wʌn baɪ wʌn ðeɪ əpɪɹd, ə dʌzən ə ðɛm ɔl toʊld, tə æsk ɪf ðə hjumənz wɝ kʌmftəɹbəl, ɪf ðeɪ niɾəd ɛniθɪŋ. itʃ tɝn əɹ ətɛnʃənz tə lɔɪəl dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ ʃi lɛft. hi ɡeɪv ɪz ænsɝz ɹɪspɛkfəli bʌɾ ɪn əz fju wɝdz əz ɹænd hæɾ ɛvɝ hɝɾ ɪm juz, stændɪŋ wɪð ən oʊɡiɝ-saɪzd, wʊd-baʊn bʊk klʌtʃt tə hɪz tʃɛs laɪk ə ʃild, ən wən ðeɪ wɛnt, hi hʌɾəld ɪn ɪz tʃɛɹ wɪð ðə bʊk hɛld ʌp ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪz feɪs. ðə bʊks ɪn ðə haʊs wɝ wʌn θɪŋ nɑt saɪz fəɹ hjumənz.

Ogier girls brought water and towels for washing faces and hands, and cheese and fruit and wine, with pewter goblets a little too large to be comfortable in the hand. Other Ogier women came, too, their dresses all embroidered. One by one they appeared, a dozen of them all told, to ask if the humans were comfortable, if they needed anything. Each turned her attentions to Loial just before she left. He gave his answers respectfully but in as few words as Rand had ever heard him use, standing with an Ogier-sized, wood-bound book clutched to his chest like a shield, and when they went, he huddled in his chair with the book held up in front of his face. The books in the house were one thing not sized for humans.

"dʒʌst smɛl ðɪs ɛɹ, lɔɹd ɹænd," hʊɹɪn sɛd, fɪlɪŋ ɪz lʌŋz wɪð ə smaɪl. hɪz fit dæŋɡəl fɹəm wʌn ə ðə tʃɛɹz ət ðə teɪbəl; hi swʌŋ əm laɪk ə bɔɪ. "aɪ nɛvɝ θɔt moʊs pleɪsəz smɛl bæd, bʌt ðɪs. . . . lɔɹd ɹænd, aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðɛɹz ɛvɝ bɪn ɛni kɪlɪŋ hɪɹ. nɑɾ ivən ɛni hɝɾɪŋ, ɪksɛp baɪ æksəɾənt."

"Just smell this air, Lord Rand," Hurin said, filling his lungs with a smile. His feet dangled from one of the chairs at the table; he swung them like a boy. "I never thought most places smelled bad, but this. . . . Lord Rand, I don't think there's ever been any killing here. Not even any hurting, except by accident."

"ðə stɛɾɪŋ ɑɹ səpoʊz tə bi seɪf fəɹ ɛvɹiwʌn," ɹænd sɛd. hi wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ lɔɪəl. "ðæts wʌt ðə stɔɹiz seɪ, ɛniweɪ." hi swɑloʊɾ ə læs bɪɾ ʌv waɪt tʃiz ən wɛn oʊvɝ tə ði oʊɡiɝ. mæt fɑloʊd wɪð ə ɡɑbləɾ ɪn ɪz hænd. "wʌts ðə mæɾɝ, lɔɪəl?" ɹænd sɛd. "juv bɪn əz nɝvəs əz ə kæɾ ɪn ə dɔɡjɑɹɾ ɛvɝ sɪns wi keɪm hɪɹ."

"The stedding are supposed to be safe for everyone," Rand said. He was watching Loial. "That's what the stories say, anyway." He swallowed a last bit of white cheese and went over to the Ogier. Mat followed with a goblet in his hand. "What's the matter, Loial?" Rand said. "You've been as nervous as a cat in a dogyard ever since we came here."

"ɪɾ ɪz nʌθɪŋ," lɔɪəl sɛd, ɡɪvɪŋ ðə dɔɹ ən ənizi ɡlæns fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz aɪ.

"It is nothing," Loial said, giving the door an uneasy glance from the corner of his eye.

"ɑɹ jə əfɹeɪd ðəl faɪn aʊt jə lɛf stɛɾɪŋ ʃæŋktaɪ wɪθaʊt pɝmɪʃən fɹəm jəɹ ɛldɝz?"

"Are you afraid they'll find out you left Stedding Shangtai without permission from your Elders?"

lɔɪəl lʊkt ɝaʊnd waɪldli, ðə tʌfs ɑn ɪz ɪɹz vaɪbɹeɪɾɪŋ. "doʊn seɪ ðæt," hi hɪst. "nɑt wɛɹ ɛniwʌn kən hɪɹ. ɪf ðeɪ faʊn aʊt. . . ." wɪð ə hɛvi saɪ, hi slʌmp bæk, lʊkɪŋ fɹəm ɹænd tə mæt. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ haʊ hjumənz də ɪt, bʌɾ əmʌŋ oʊɡiɝ. . . . ɪf ə ɡɝl siz ə bɔɪ ʃi laɪks, ʃi ɡoʊz tə hɝ mʌðɝ. əɹ səmtaɪmz ðə mʌðɝ siz sʌmwʌn ʃi θɪŋks ɪz suɾəbəl. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ɪf ðeɪ əɡɹi, ðə ɡɝlz mʌðɝ ɡoʊz tə ðə bɔɪz mʌðɝ, ən ðə nɛks θɪŋ ðə bɔɪ noʊz, hɪz mɛɹɪdʒ ɪz ɔl ɝeɪnʒd."

Loial looked around wildly, the tufts on his ears vibrating. "Don't say that," he hissed. "Not where anyone can hear. If they found out. . . ." With a heavy sigh, he slumped back, looking from Rand to Mat. "I don't know how humans do it, but among Ogier. . . . If a girl sees a boy she likes, she goes to her mother. Or sometimes the mother sees someone she thinks is suitable. In any case, if they agree, the girl's mother goes to the boy's mother, and the next thing the boy knows, his marriage is all arranged."

"dʌzn ðə bɔɪ hæv ɛni seɪ ɪn ɪt?" mæt æskt ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli.

"Doesn't the boy have any say in it?" Mat asked incredulously.

"nʌn. ðə wɪmən ɔlweɪz seɪ wi wəd spɛn əɹ lɪvz mɛɹid tə ðə tʃɹiz ɪf ɪt wɑz lɛf tə ʌs." lɔɪəl ʃɪftəd, ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ. "hæf ʌv əɹ mɛɹɪdʒɪz teɪk pleɪs bɪtwin stɛɾɪŋ; ɡɹups ə jʌŋ oʊɡiɝ vɪzət fɹəm stɛɾɪŋ tə stɛɾɪŋ soʊ ðeɪ kən si, ən bi sin. ɪf ðeɪ dɪskʌvɝ aɪm aʊtsaɪd wɪθaʊt pɝmɪʃən, ði ɛldɝz wɪl ɔlmoʊst sɝɾənli dɪsaɪɾ aɪ niɾ ə waɪf tə sɛɾəl mi daʊn. bɪfɔɹ aɪ noʊ ɪt, ðəl əv sɛn ə mɛsədʒ tə stɛɾɪŋ ʃæŋktaɪ, tə maɪ mʌðɝ, ən ʃɪl kʌm hɪɹ ən əv mi mɛɹid bɪfɔɹ ʃi wɑʃɪz ɔf ðə dʌst ə hɝ dʒɝni. ʃiz ɔlweɪz sɛɾ aɪm tu heɪsti ən niɾ ə waɪf. aɪ θɪŋk ʃi wɑz lʊkɪŋ wən aɪ lɛft. wʌtɛvɝ waɪf ʃi tʃuzəz fəɹ mi . . . wɛl, ɛni waɪf əɾ ɔl woʊn lemi ɡoʊ bæk aʊtsaɪɾ əntɪl aɪ hæv ɡɹeɪ ɪn maɪ bɪɹd. waɪvz ɔlweɪz seɪ noʊ mæn ʃəd bi əlaʊɾ aʊtsaɪɾ əntɪl hiz sɛɾəld ɪnʌf tə kəntʃɹoʊl ɪz tɛmpɝ."

"None. The women always say we would spend our lives married to the trees if it was left to us." Loial shifted, grimacing. "Half of our marriages take place between stedding; groups of young Ogier visit from stedding to stedding so they can see, and be seen. If they discover I'm Outside without permission, the Elders will almost certainly decide I need a wife to settle me down. Before I know it, they'll have sent a message to Stedding Shangtai, to my mother, and she will come here and have me married before she washes off the dust of her journey. She's always said I am too hasty and need a wife. I think she was looking when I left. Whatever wife she chooses for me . . . well, any wife at all won't let me go back Outside until I have gray in my beard. Wives always say no man should be allowed Outside until he's settled enough to control his temper."

mæt ɡeɪv ə ɡʌfɔ laʊɾ ɪnʌf tə dʒɹɔ ɛvɹi hɛd, bʌɾ ət lɔɪəlz fɹæntɪk dʒɛstʃɝ i spoʊk sɔfli. "əmʌŋ ʌs, mɛn də ðə tʃuzɪŋ, ən noʊ waɪf kən stɑp ə mæn duɪŋ wʌɾ i wɑns."

Mat gave a guffaw loud enough to draw every head, but at Loial's frantic gesture he spoke softly. "Among us, men do the choosing, and no wife can stop a man doing what he wants."

ɹænd fɹaʊnd, ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ haʊ ɛɡwin hæd bɪɡʌn fɑloʊɪŋ ɪm ɝaʊnd wən ðeɪ wɝ boʊθ lɪɾəl. ɪt wɑz ðən ðət mɪstʃɹəs ælvɪɹ hæd bɪɡʌn teɪkɪŋ ə spɛʃəl ɪntʃɹəst ɪn hɪm, mɔɹ ðən ɪn ɛni ʌv ði ʌðɝ bɔɪz. leɪɾɝ, səm ɡɝlz wəd dæns wɪð ɪm ɑn fistdeɪz ən səm wəd nɑt, ən ðoʊz u wəd wɝ ɔlweɪz ɛɡwinz fɹɛnz, waɪl ðoʊz u wəd nɑt wɝ ɡɝlz ɛɡwin dɪd nɑt laɪk. hi ɔlsoʊ sim tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ mɪstʃɹəs ælvɪɹ teɪkɪŋ tæm əsaɪd - ən ʃi wɑz mʌɾɝɪŋ əbaʊt tæm nɑt hævɪŋ ə waɪf fəɹ əɹ tə tɔk tə! - ən æftɝ ðæt, tæm ən ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls hæɾ æktəɾ əz ɪf i ən ɛɡwin wɝ pɹɑməst, ivən ðoʊ ðeɪ hæd nɑt nɛl bɪfɔɹ ðə wɪmənz sɝkəl tə seɪ ðə wɝdz. hi hæd nɛvɝ θɔɾ əbaʊɾ ɪt ðɪs weɪ bɪfɔɹ; θɪŋz bɪtwin ɛɡwin ən ɪm hæɾ ɔlweɪz dʒʌst sim tə bi ðə weɪ ðeɪ wɝ, ən ðət wɑz ðæt.

Rand frowned, remembering how Egwene had begun following him around when they were both little. It was then that Mistress al'Vere had begun taking a special interest in him, more than in any of the other boys. Later, some girls would dance with him on feastdays and some would not, and those who would were always Egwene's friends, while those who would not were girls Egwene did not like. He also seemed to remember Mistress al'Vere taking Tam aside - And she was muttering about Tam not having a wife for her to talk to! - and after that, Tam and everyone else had acted as if he and Egwene were promised, even though they had not knelt before the Women's Circle to say the words. He had never thought about it this way before; things between Egwene and him had always just seemed to be the way they were, and that was that.

"aɪ θɪŋk wi də ɪt ðə seɪm weɪ," hi mʌɾɝd, ən wən mæt læft, hi æɾəd, "du jə ɹɪmɛmbɝ jəɹ fɑðɝ ɛvɝ duɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ jəɹ mʌðɝ ɹɪli dɪdnt wɑn ɪm tə?" mæt oʊpən ɪz maʊθ wɪð ə ɡɹɪn, ðən fɹaʊn θɔtfəli ən kloʊzd ɪɾ əɡɛn.

"I think we do it the same way," he muttered, and when Mat laughed, he added, "Do you remember your father ever doing anything your mother really didn't want him to?" Mat opened his mouth with a grin, then frowned thoughtfully and closed it again.

dʒun keɪm daʊn ðə stɛps fɹəm aʊtsaɪd. "ɪf jə pliz, wɪl ɔl ə jə kʌm wɪð mi? ði ɛldɝz wəd si ju." hi dɪd nɑt lʊk ət lɔɪəl, bʌt lɔɪəl stɪl ɔlmoʊs dʒɹɑp ðə bʊk.

Juin came down the steps from outside. "If you please, will all of you come with me? The Elders would see you." He did not look at Loial, but Loial still almost dropped the book.

"ɪf ði ɛldɝz tʃɹaɪ tə meɪk jə steɪ," ɹænd sɛd, "wil seɪ wi nid jə tə ɡoʊ wɪð ʌs."

"If the Elders try to make you stay," Rand said, "we'll say we need you to go with us."

"aɪl bɛɾ ɪɾ ɪzən əbaʊt jə əɾ ɔl," mæt sɛd. "aɪl bɛt ðeɪ ɑɹ dʒʌs gɑnə seɪ wi kən juz ðə weɪɡeɪt." hi ʃʊk hɪmsɛlf, ən ɪz vɔɪs fɛl ivən loʊɝ. "wi ɹɪli hæv tə də ɪt, doʊnt wi." ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə kwɛstʃən.

"I'll bet it isn't about you at all," Mat said. "I'll bet they are just going to say we can use the Waygate." He shook himself, and his voice fell even lower. "We really have to do it, don't we." It was not a question.

"steɪ ən ɡɛt mɛɹid, əɹ tʃɹævəl ðə weɪz." lɔɪəl ɡɹɪməst ɹufəli. "laɪf ɪz vɛɹi ənsɛɾəlɪŋ wɪð tɑvɝən fəɹ fɹɛnz."

"Stay and get married, or travel the Ways." Loial grimaced ruefully. "Life is very unsettling with ta'veren for friends."


tʃæptɝ θɝɾisɪks


CHAPTER 36

əmʌŋ ði ɛldɝz


Among the Elders

əz dʒun tʊk əm θɹu ði oʊɡiɝ taʊn, ɹænd sɔ ðət lɔɪəl wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ mɔɹ ən mɔɹ æŋkʃəs. lɔɪəlz ɪɹz wɝ əz stɪf əz ɪz bæk; hɪz aɪz ɡɹu bɪɡɝ ɛvɹi taɪm i sɔ ənʌðɝ oʊɡiɝ lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm, ɪspɛʃli ðə wɪmən ən ɡɝlz, ən ə lɑɹdʒ nʌmbɝ ə ðɛm dɪd sim tə teɪk noʊɾəs ə hɪm. hi lʊkt əz ɪf i ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪz oʊn ɛksəkjuʃən.

As Juin took them through the Ogier town, Rand saw that Loial was growing more and more anxious. Loial's ears were as stiff as his back; his eyes grew bigger every time he saw another Ogier looking at him, especially the women and girls, and a large number of them did seem to take notice of him. He looked as if he expected his own execution.

ðə bɪɹɾəd oʊɡiɝ dʒɛstʃɝd tə waɪd stɛps liɾɪŋ daʊn ɪndə ə ɡɹæsi maʊn ðət wɑz bɪɡɝ baɪ fɑɹ ðən ɛni ʌðɝ; ɪt wɑz ə hɪl, fəɹ ɔl pɹæktəkəl pɝpəsəz, ɔlmoʊst ət ðə beɪs ʌv wʌn ə ðə ɡɹeɪt tʃɹiz.

The bearded Ogier gestured to wide steps leading down into a grassy mound that was bigger by far than any other; it was a hill, for all practical purposes, almost at the base of one of the Great Trees.

"waɪ doʊn jə weɪɾ aʊt hɪɹ, lɔɪəl?" ɹænd sɛd.

"Why don't you wait out here, Loial?" Rand said.

"ði ɛldɝz - " dʒun bɪɡæn.

"The Elders - " Juin began.

" - pɹɑbli dʒʌst wɑnə si ðə ɹɛst ʌv ʌs," ɹænd fɪnɪʃt fəɹ hɪm.

" - Probably just want to see the rest of us," Rand finished for him.

"waɪ doʊn ðeɪ liv ɪm əloʊn," mæt pʊɾ ɪn.

"Why don't they leave him alone," Mat put in.

lɔɪəl nɑɾəd vɪɡɝəsli. "jɛs. jɛs, aɪ θɪŋk. . . ." ə nʌmbɝ ʌv oʊɡiɝ wɪmən wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm, fɹəm waɪt-hɛɹd ɡɹændmʌðɝz tə dɔɾɝz ɛɹɪθs eɪdʒ, ə nɑɾ ə ðɛm tɔkɪŋ əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz bʌt wɪð ɔl aɪz ɑn hɪm. hɪz ɪɹz dʒɝkt, bʌɾ i lʊkt ət ðə bɹɔd dɔɹ tə wɪtʃ ðə stoʊn stɛps lɛd daʊn, ən nɑɾəd əɡɛn. "jɛs, əl sɪɾ aʊt hɪɹ, ən əl ɹɛd. ðəɾ ɪz ɪt. əl ɹid." fʌmbəlɪŋ ɪn ɪz koʊt pɑkət, hi pɹədust ə bʊk. hi sɛɾəld hɪmsɛlf ɑn ðə maʊn bɪsaɪd ðə stɛps, ðə bʊk smɔl ɪn ɪz hænz, ən fɪkst ɪz aɪz ɑn ðə peɪdʒəz. "aɪ wɪl dʒʌst sɪt hɪɹ ən ɹɛɾ əntɪl jə kʌm aʊt." hɪz ɪɹz twɪtʃt əz ɪf i kəd fil ðə wɪmənz aɪz.

Loial nodded vigorously. "Yes. Yes, I think. . . ." A number of Ogier women were watching him, from white-haired grandmothers to daughters Erith's age, a knot of them talking among themselves but with all eyes on him. His ears jerked, but he looked at the broad door to which the stone steps led down, and nodded again. "Yes, I will sit out here, and I'll read. That is it. I will read." Fumbling in his coat pocket, he produced a book. He settled himself on the mound beside the steps, the book small in his hands, and fixed his eyes on the pages. "I will just sit here and read until you come out." His ears twitched as if he could feel the women's eyes.

dʒun ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, ðən ʃɹʌɡd ən moʊʃən tə ðə stɛps əɡɛn. "ɪf jə pliz. ði ɛldɝz ɑɹ weɪɾɪŋ."

Juin shook his head, then shrugged and motioned to the steps again. "If you please. The Elders are waiting."

ðə hjudʒ, wɪndoʊləs ɹum ɪnsaɪd ðə maʊnd wɑz skeɪl fəɹ oʊɡiɝ, wɪð ə θɪk-bim silɪŋ mɔɹ ðən fɔɹ spænz ʌp; ɪt cʊɾə fɪɾ ɪn ɛni pæləs, fəɹ saɪz ət list. ðə sɛvən oʊɡiɝ siɾəd ɑn ðə deɪz dɝɛkli ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə dɔɹ meɪɾ ɪt ʃɹɪŋk ə lɪɾəl baɪ ðɛɹ saɪz, bʌt ɹænd stɪl fɛlt əz ɪf i wɝ ɪn ə kævɝn. ðə sɑmbɝ flɔɹstoʊnz wɝ smuð, ɪf lɑɹdʒ ən ɪɹɛɡjəlɝ ɪn ʃeɪp, bʌt ðə ɡɹeɪ wɔlz cʊɾə bɪn ðə ɹʌf saɪɾ ʌv ə klɪf. ðə silɪŋ bimz, ɹʌf-hjun əz ðeɪ wɝ, lʊk laɪk ɡɹeɪt ɹuts.

The huge, windowless room inside the mound was scaled for Ogier, with a thick-beamed ceiling more than four spans up; it could have fit in any palace, for size at least. The seven Ogier seated on the dais directly in front of the door made it shrink a little by their size, but Rand still felt as if he were in a cavern. The somber floorstones were smooth, if large and irregular in shape, but the gray walls could have been the rough side of a cliff. The ceiling beams, rough-hewn as they were, looked like great roots.

ɪksɛp fəɹ ə haɪ-bæk tʃɛɹ wɛɹ vɛɹɪn sæt feɪsɪŋ ðə deɪz, ði oʊnli fɝnɪʃɪŋz wɝ ðə hɛvi, vaɪn-kɑɹv tʃɛɹz ə ði ɛldɝz. ði oʊɡiɝ wʊmən ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə deɪz sæɾ ɪn ə tʃɛɹ ɹeɪzd ə lɪɾəl haɪɝ ðən ðoʊz ə ði ʌðɝz, θɹi bɪɹɾəd mɛn tə hɝ lɛft ɪn lɔŋ, flɛɹɪŋ koʊts, θɹi wɪmən tə hɝ ɹaɪɾ ɪn dʒɹɛsəz laɪk əɹ oʊn, ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɪn vaɪnz ən flaʊɝz fɹəm nɛklaɪn tə hɛm. ɔl hæɾ eɪdʒ feɪsəz ən pjʊɹ waɪt hɛɹ, ivən tə ðə tʌfs ɑn ðɛɹ ɪɹz, ən ən ɛɹ ə mæsɪv dɪɡnəɾi.

Except for a high-backed chair where Verin sat facing the dais, the only furnishings were the heavy, vine-carved chairs of the Elders. The Ogier woman in the middle of the dais sat in a chair raised a little higher than those of the others, three bearded men to her left in long, flaring coats, three women to her right in dresses like her own, embroidered in vines and flowers from neckline to hem. All had aged faces and pure white hair, even to the tufts on their ears, and an air of massive dignity.

hʊɹɪn ɡeɪpt əɾ əm oʊpənli, ən ɹænd fɛlt laɪk stɛɹɪŋ hɪmsɛlf. nɑɾ ivən vɛɹɪn hæd ði əpɪɹəns ʌv wɪzdəm ðət wɑz ɪn ði ɛldɝz' hjudʒ aɪz, nɔɹ mɔɹɡeɪs ɪn əɹ kɹaʊn ðɛɹ əθɔɹəɾi, nɔɹ mɔɪɹeɪn ðɛɹ kɑm sɝɛnəɾi. ɪŋtʃɹ wɑz ðə fɝs tə baʊ, əz fɔɹməli əz ɹænd hæɾ ɛvɝ sin fɹəm hɪm, waɪl ði ʌðɝz stɪl stʊd ɹuɾəd.

Hurin gaped at them openly, and Rand felt like staring himself. Not even Verin had the appearance of wisdom that was in the Elders' huge eyes, nor Morgase in her crown their authority, nor Moiraine their calm serenity. Ingtar was the first to bow, as formally as Rand had ever seen from him, while the others still stood rooted.

"aɪ æm eɪlɑɹ," ði oʊɡiɝ wʊmən ɑn ðə haɪəs tʃɛɹ sɛd wən ðeɪ hæd faɪnəli teɪkən ðɛɹ pleɪsəz bɪsaɪd vɛɹɪn, "ɛldəst ə ði ɛldɝz ə stɛɾɪŋ tsəfu. vɛɹɪn əz toʊld əs ðət juv nid tə juz ðə weɪɡeɪt hɪɹ. tə ɹɪkʌvɝ ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ fɹəm dɑɹkfɹɛnz ɪz ə ɡɹeɪt nid, ɪndid, bʌt wɪv əlaʊd nʌn tə tʃɹævəl ðə weɪz ɪn mɔɹ ðən wʌn hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz. niðɝ ʌs, nɔɹ ði ɛldɝz ʌv ɛni ʌðɝ stɛɾɪŋ."

"I am Alar," the Ogier woman on the highest chair said when they had finally taken their places beside Verin, "Eldest of the Elders of Stedding Tsofu. Verin has told us that you have need to use the Waygate here. To recover the Horn of Valere from Darkfriends is a great need, indeed, but we have allowed none to travel the Ways in more than one hundred years. Neither us, nor the Elders of any other stedding."

"aɪ wɪl faɪn ðə hɔɹn," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛɾ æŋɡɹəli. "aɪ mʌst. ɪf jəl nɑt pɝmɪɾ əs tə juz ðə weɪɡeɪt. . . ." hi fɛl saɪlən əz vɛɹɪn lʊkt ət hɪm, bʌt ðə skaʊl ɹɪmeɪn ɑn ɪz feɪs.

"I will find the Horn," Ingtar said angrily. "I must. If you will not permit us to use the Waygate. . . ." He fell silent as Verin looked at him, but the scowl remained on his face.

eɪlɑɹ smaɪld. "bi nɑt soʊ heɪsti, ʃaɪnɝən. jə hjumənz nɛvɝ teɪk taɪm fəɹ θɔt. oʊnli dɪsɪʒənz ɹitʃt ɪn kɑm kən bi ʃʊɹ." hɝ smaɪl feɪɾəd tə sɪɹiəsnəs, bʌɾ əɹ vɔɪs kɛpt ɪts oʊn mɛʒɝd kɑm. "ðə deɪnʒɝz ə ðə weɪz ɑɹ nɑt tə bi feɪst wɪð ə sɔɹɾ ɪn jəɹ hænd, nɑt tʃɑɹdʒɪŋ il əɹ ɹeɪvinɪŋ tʃɹɑləks. aɪ mʌs tɛl jə ðət tə ɛntɝ ðə weɪz ɪz tə ɹɪsk nɑɾ oʊnli dɛθ ən mædnəs, bʌt pɝhæps jəɹ vɛɹi soʊlz."

Alar smiled. "Be not so hasty, Shienaran. You humans never take time for thought. Only decisions reached in calm can be sure." Her smile faded to seriousness, but her voice kept its own measured calm. "The dangers of the Ways are not to be faced with a sword in your hand, not charging Aiel or ravening Trollocs. I must tell you that to enter the Ways is to risk not only death and madness, but perhaps your very souls."

"wi hæv sin mætʃɪn ʃɪn," ɹænd sɛd, ən mæt ən pɛɹɪn əɡɹid. ðeɪ kəd nɑt mænədʒ tə saʊn iɡɝ tə də ɪɾ əɡɛn.

"We have seen Machin Shin," Rand said, and Mat and Perrin agreed. They could not manage to sound eager to do it again.

"aɪ wɪl fɑloʊ ðə hɔɹn tə ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl ɪtsɛlf, ɪf nid bi," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd fɝmli. hʊɹɪn oʊnli nɑɾəd əz ɪf ɪnkluɾɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ɪn ɪŋtʃɹz wɝdz.

"I will follow the Horn to Shayol Ghul itself, if need be," Ingtar said firmly. Hurin only nodded as if including himself in Ingtar's words.

"bɹɪŋ tʃɹəl," eɪlɑɹ kəmændəd, ən dʒun, hu hæd ɹɪmeɪn baɪ ðə dɔɹ, baʊɾ ən lɛft. "ɪɾ ɪz nɑɾ ɪnʌf," ʃi toʊl vɛɹɪn, "tə hɪɹ wʌt kən hæpən. jə mʌst si ɪt, noʊ ɪɾ ɪn jəɹ hɑɹt."

"Bring Trayal," Alar commanded, and Juin, who had remained by the door, bowed and left. "It is not enough," she told Verin, "to hear what can happen. You must see it, know it in your heart."

ðəɹ wɑz ən ənkʌmftəɹbəl saɪləns əntɪl dʒun ɹɪtɝnd, ən ɪt bɪkeɪm mɔɹ ənkʌmftəɹbəl stɪl əz tu oʊɡiɝ wɪmən fɑloʊd hɪm, ɡaɪɾɪŋ ə dɑɹk-bɪɹɾəd oʊɡiɝ ə mɪɾəl jɪɹz, hu ʃæmbəl bɪtwin əm əz ɪf i dɪd nɑt kwaɪt noʊ haʊ hɪz lɛɡz wɝkt. hɪz feɪs sæɡd, wɪθaʊɾ ɛni ɪkspɹɛʃən əɾ ɔl, ən ɪz bɪɡ aɪz wɝ veɪkən ən ənblɪŋkɪŋ, nɑt stɛɹɪŋ, nɑt lʊkɪŋ, nɑɾ ivən simɪŋ tə si. wʌn ə ðə wɪmən dʒɛnli waɪp dʒɹul fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz maʊθ. ðeɪ tʊk ɪz ɑɹmz tə stɑp hɪm; hɪz fʊt wɛn fɔɹwɝd, hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən fɛl bæk wɪð ə θʌmp. hi simd əz kɑntɛn tə stæn əz tə wɔk, əɹ ət list əz ənkɛɹɪŋ.

There was an uncomfortable silence until Juin returned, and it became more uncomfortable still as two Ogier women followed him, guiding a dark-bearded Ogier of middle years, who shambled between them as if he did not quite know how his legs worked. His face sagged, without any expression at all, and his big eyes were vacant and unblinking, not staring, not looking, not even seeming to see. One of the women gently wiped drool from the corner of his mouth. They took his arms to stop him; his foot went forward, hesitated, then fell back with a thump. He seemed as content to stand as to walk, or at least as uncaring.

"tʃɹəl wɑz wʌn ə ðə læst əmʌŋ əs tə ɡoʊ əlɔŋ ðə weɪz," eɪlɑɹ sɛd sɔfli. "hi keɪm aʊɾ əz jə si hɪm. wɪl jə tʌtʃ hɪm, vɛɹɪn?"

"Trayal was one of the last among us to go along the Ways," Alar said softly. "He came out as you see him. Will you touch him, Verin?"

vɛɹɪn ɡeɪv əɹ ə lɔŋ lʊk, ðən ɹoʊz ən stʃɹoʊd tə tʃɹəl. hi dɪd nɑt muv əz ʃi leɪɾ əɹ hænz ɑn ɪz waɪd tʃɛst, nɑɾ ivən ə flɪkɝ ʌv ən aɪ tə æknɑlɪdʒ əɹ tʌtʃ. wɪð ə ʃɑɹp hɪs, ʃi dʒɝk bæk, stɛɹɪŋ ʌp ət hɪm, ðən wɝl tə feɪs ði ɛldɝz. "hi ɪz . . . ɛmpti. ðɪs bɑɾi laɪvz, bʌt ðəɹ ɪz nʌθɪŋ ɪnsaɪɾ ɪt. nʌθɪŋ." ɛvɹi ɛldɝ wɔɹ ə lʊk ʌv ənbɛɹəbəl sædnəs.

Verin gave her a long look, then rose and strode to Trayal. He did not move as she laid her hands on his wide chest, not even a flicker of an eye to acknowledge her touch. With a sharp hiss, she jerked back, staring up at him, then whirled to face the Elders. "He is . . . empty. This body lives, but there is nothing inside it. Nothing." Every Elder wore a look of unbearable sadness.

"nʌθɪŋ," wʌn ə ði ɛldɝz tə eɪlɑɹz ɹaɪt sɛd sɔfli. hɝ aɪz sim tə hoʊld ɔl ðə peɪn tʃɹəlz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ kʊd. "noʊ maɪnd. noʊ soʊl. nʌθɪŋ ə tʃɹəl ɹɪmeɪnz bʌɾ ɪz bɑɾi."

"Nothing," one of the Elders to Alar's right said softly. Her eyes seemed to hold all the pain Trayal's no longer could. "No mind. No soul. Nothing of Trayal remains but his body."

"hi wɑz ə faɪn tʃɹisɪŋʒɝ," wʌn ə ðə mɛn saɪd.

"He was a fine Treesinger," one of the men sighed.

eɪlɑɹ moʊʃənd, ən ðə tu wɪmən tɝn tʃɹəl tə liɾ ɪm aʊt; ðeɪ hæd tə muv ɪm bɪfɔɹ i bɪɡæn tə wɔk.

Alar motioned, and the two women turned Trayal to lead him out; they had to move him before he began to walk.

"wi noʊ ðə ɹɪsks," vɛɹɪn sɛd. "bʌt wʌtɛvɝ ðə ɹɪsks, wi mʌs fɑloʊ ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ."

"We know the risks," Verin said. "But whatever the risks, we must follow the Horn of Valere."

ði ɛldəs nɑɾəd. "ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ. aɪ də nɑt noʊ wɛðɝ ɪts wɝs nuz ðəɾ ɪts ɪn dɑɹkfɹɛn hænz, əɹ ðəɾ ɪts bɪn faʊn əɾ ɔl." ʃi lʊk daʊn ðə ɹoʊ ʌv ɛldɝz; itʃ nɑɾəd ɪn tɝn, wʌn ə ðə mɛn tʌɡɪŋ ɪz bɪɹd daʊtfəli fɝst. "vɛɹi wɛl. vɛɹɪn tɛlz mi taɪm ɪz ɝdʒənt. əl ʃoʊ jə tə ðə weɪɡeɪt maɪsɛlf." ɹænd wɑz filɪŋ hæf ɹɪlivd ən hæf əfɹeɪd, wən ʃi æɾəd, "ju hæv wɪð jə ə jʌŋ oʊɡiɝ. lɔɪəl, sʌn ʌv ɑɹən sʌn ə hɑlən, fɹəm stɛɾɪŋ ʃæŋktaɪ. hiz fɑɹ fɹəm ɪz hoʊm."

The Eldest nodded. "The Horn of Valere. I do not know whether it is worse news that it is in Darkfriend hands, or that it has been found at all." She looked down the row of Elders; each nodded in turn, one of the men tugging his beard doubtfully first. "Very well. Verin tells me time is urgent. I will show you to the Waygate myself." Rand was feeling half relieved and half afraid, when she added, "You have with you a young Ogier. Loial, son of Arent son of Halan, from Stedding Shangtai. He is far from his home."

"wi nid hɪm," ɹænd sɛd kwɪkli. hɪz wɝdz sloʊɾ ʌndɝ sɝpɹaɪz stɛɹz fɹəm ði ɛldɝz ən vɛɹɪn, bʌɾ i wɛn ɑn stʌbɝnli. "wi niɾ ɪm tə ɡoʊ wɪð ʌs, ən i wɑns tə."

"We need him," Rand said quickly. His words slowed under surprised stares from the Elders and Verin, but he went on stubbornly. "We need him to go with us, and he wants to."

"lɔɪəlz ə fɹɛnd," pɛɹɪn sɛd, ət ðə seɪm taɪm ðət mæt sɛd, "hi dʌznt ɡɛɾ ɪn ðə weɪ, ən i kæɹiz ɪz oʊn weɪt." niðɝ ə ðɛm əpɪɹd kʌmftəɹbəl ət hævɪŋ ði ɛldɝz' foʊkəs ʃɪf tə ðɛm, bʌt ðeɪ dɪd nɑt bæk daʊn.

"Loial's a friend," Perrin said, at the same time that Mat said, "He doesn't get in the way, and he carries his own weight." Neither of them appeared comfortable at having the Elders' focus shift to them, but they did not back down.

"ɪz ðəɹ səm ɹizən i kænɑt kʌm wɪð ʌs?" ɪŋtʃɹ æskt. "æz mæt sɛz, hiz hɛld ɪz oʊn. aɪ doʊnt noʊ ðət wi nid hɪm, bʌɾ ɪf i wɑns tə kʌm, waɪ - ?"

"Is there some reason he cannot come with us?" Ingtar asked. "As Mat says, he has held his own. I don't know that we need him, but if he wants to come, why - ?"

"wi də nid hɪm," vɛɹɪn bɹoʊk ɪn smuðli. "fju ɛni lɔŋɡɝ noʊ ðə weɪz, bʌt lɔɪəl əz stʌɾid ðɛm. hi kən dɪsaɪfɝ ðə ɡaɪɾɪŋz."

"We do need him," Verin broke in smoothly. "Few any longer know the Ways, but Loial has studied them. He can decipher the Guidings."

eɪlɑɹ aɪɾ əm itʃ ɪn tɝn, ðən sɛɾəld tə ə stʌɾi ʌv ɹænd. ʃi lʊkt əz ɪf ʃi nu θɪŋz; ɔl ði ɛldɝz dɪd, bʌt ʃi moʊst ʌv ɔl. "vɛɹɪn sɛz jə ɑɹ tɑvɝən," ʃi sɛɾ ət læst, "æn aɪ kən fil ɪɾ ɪn ju. ðəɾ aɪ kən də soʊ minz ðət jə mʌs bi vɛɹi stʃɹɔŋli tɑvɝən ɪndid, fəɹ sətʃ tæləns ɛvɝ ɹʌn wikli ɪn ʌs, ɪf əɾ ɔl. hæv jə dʒɹɔn lɔɪəl, sʌn ʌv ɑɹən sʌn ə hɑlən, ɪndə tæmɹəleɪlən, ðə wɛb ðə pæɾɝn wivz ɝaʊn ju?"

Alar eyed them each in turn, then settled to a study of Rand. She looked as if she knew things; all the Elders did, but she most of all. "Verin says you are ta'veren," she said at last, "and I can feel it in you. That I can do so means that you must be very strongly ta'veren indeed, for such Talents ever run weakly in us, if at all. Have you drawn Loial, son of Arent son of Halan, into ta'maral'ailen, the Web the Pattern weaves around you?"

"aɪ. . . . aɪ dʒʌst wɑnə faɪn ðə hɔɹn ænd. . . ." ɹænd lɛt ðə ɹɛst ʌv ɪt daɪ. eɪlɑɹ hæd nɑt mɛnʃən mæts dæɡɝ. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ wɛðɝ vɛɹɪn hæd toʊl ði ɛldɝz, əɹ hɛld ɪt bæk fəɹ səm ɹizən. "hi ɪz maɪ fɹɛnd, ɛldəst."

"I. . . . I just want to find the Horn and. . . ." Rand let the rest of it die. Alar had not mentioned Mat's dagger. He did not know whether Verin had told the Elders, or held it back for some reason. "He is my friend, Eldest."

"jɔɹ fɹɛnd," eɪlɑɹ sɛd. "hi ɪz jʌŋ baɪ əɹ weɪ ʌv θɪŋkɪŋ. jə ɑɹ jʌŋ, tu, bʌt tɑvɝən. jəl lʊk æftɝ hɪm, ən wən ðə wivɪŋ ɪz dʌn, jəl si ðəɾ i kʌmz seɪfli hoʊm tə stɛɾɪŋ ʃæŋktaɪ."

"Your friend," Alar said. "He is young by our way of thinking. You are young, too, but ta'veren. You will look after him, and when the weaving is done, you will see that he comes safely home to Stedding Shangtai."

"aɪ wɪl," hi toʊl hɝ. ɪt hæd ðə filɪŋ ʌv ə kəmɪtmənt, ðə swɛɹɪŋ ʌv ən oʊθ.

"I will," he told her. It had the feeling of a commitment, the swearing of an oath.

"ðɛn wɪl ɡoʊ tə ðə weɪɡeɪt."

"Then we will go to the Waygate."

aʊtsaɪd, lɔɪəl skɹæmbəl tə hɪz fit wən ðeɪ əpɪɹd, eɪlɑɹ ən vɛɹɪn liɾɪŋ. ɪŋtʃɹ sɛn hʊɹɪn ɔf əɾ ə ɹʌn tə fɛtʃ ənoʊ ən ði ʌðɝ soʊlʒɝz. lɔɪəl aɪd ði ɛldəst wɛɹəli, ðən fɛl ɪn wɪð ɹænd ət ðə ɹɪɹ ə ðə pɹəsɛʃən. ði oʊɡiɝ wɪmən u hæd bɪn wɑtʃɪŋ ɪm wɝ ɔl ɡɔn. "dɪd ði ɛldɝz seɪ ɛniθɪŋ əbaʊt mi? dɪd ʃi . . . ?" hi pɪɹɾ əɾ eɪlɑɹz bɹɔd bæk əz ʃi ɔɹɾɝd dʒun tə hæv ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz bɹɔt. ʃi stɑɹɾəd ɔf wɪð vɛɹɪn waɪl dʒun wɑz stɪl boʊɪŋ hɪmsɛlf əweɪ, bɛndɪŋ əɹ hɛd tə tɔk kwaɪətli.

Outside, Loial scrambled to his feet when they appeared, Alar and Verin leading. Ingtar sent Hurin off at a run to fetch Uno and the other soldiers. Loial eyed the Eldest warily, then fell in with Rand at the rear of the procession. The Ogier women who had been watching him were all gone. "Did the Elders say anything about me? Did she . . . ?" He peered at Alar's broad back as she ordered Juin to have their horses brought. She started off with Verin while Juin was still bowing himself away, bending her head to talk quietly.

"ʃi toʊld ɹænd tə teɪk kɛɹ ə ju," mæt toʊld lɔɪəl sɔləmli əz ðeɪ fɑloʊd, "æn si jə ɡɑt hoʊm seɪfli əz ə beɪb. aɪ doʊn si waɪ jə kæn steɪ hɪɹ ən ɡɛt mɛɹid."

"She told Rand to take care of you," Mat told Loial solemnly as they followed, "and see you got home safely as a babe. I don't see why you can't stay here and get married."

"ʃi sɛd jə kəd kʌm wɪð ʌs." ɹænd ɡlɛɹɾ ət mæt, wɪtʃ meɪd mæt kɔɹɾəl ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ. ɪt saʊndəɾ ɑd, kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ðət dʒɹɔn feɪs. lɔɪəl wɑz twɝlɪŋ ðə stɛm ʌv ə tʃɹuhɑɹt blɑsəm bɪtwin ɪz fɪŋɡɝz. "dɪd jə ɡoʊ pɪkɪŋ flaʊɝz?" ɹænd æskt.

"She said you could come with us." Rand glared at Mat, which made Mat chortle under his breath. It sounded odd, coming from that drawn face. Loial was twirling the stem of a trueheart blossom between his fingers. "Did you go picking flowers?" Rand asked.

"ɛɹɪθ ɡeɪv ɪt tə mi." lɔɪəl wɑtʃt ðə jɛloʊ pɛɾəlz spɪn. "ʃi ɹɪli ɪz vɛɹi pɹɪɾi, ivən ɪf mæt dʌz nɑt si ɪt."

"Erith gave it to me." Loial watched the yellow petals spin. "She really is very pretty, even if Mat does not see it."

"dʌz ðət min jə doʊnt wɑnə ɡoʊ wɪð əs æftɝ ɔl?"

"Does that mean you don't want to go with us after all?"

lɔɪəl ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt. "wʌt? oʊ, noʊ. aɪ min, jɛs. aɪ də wɑnə ɡoʊ. ʃi oʊnli ɡeɪv mi ə flaʊɝ. dʒʌst ə flaʊɝ." hi tʊk ə bʊk aʊɾ ə hɪz pɑkət, ðoʊ, ən pɹɛs ðə blɑsəm ʌndɝ ðə fɹʌn kʌvɝ. əz i ɹɪtɝn ðə bʊk, hi mɝmɝd tə hɪmsɛlf, bɛɹli laʊɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ ɹænd tə hɪɹ, "ænd ʃi sɛɾ aɪ wɑz hænsəm, tu." mæt lɛɾ aʊɾ ə wiz ən dʌbəld oʊvɝ, stæɡɝɪŋ əlɔŋ klʌtʃɪŋ ɪz saɪdz, ən lɔɪəlz tʃiks kʌlɝd. "wɛl . . . ʃi sɛɾ ɪt. aɪ dɪdnt."

Loial gave a start. "What? Oh, no. I mean, yes. I do want to go. She only gave me a flower. Just a flower." He took a book out of his pocket, though, and pressed the blossom under the front cover. As he returned the book, he murmured to himself, barely loud enough for Rand to hear, "And she said I was handsome, too." Mat let out a wheeze and doubled over, staggering along clutching his sides, and Loial's cheeks colored. "Well . . . she said it. I didn't."

pɛɹɪn ɹæp mæt smɑɹtli ɑn ðə tɑp ə hɪz hɛd wɪð ɪz nʌkəlz. "noʊbɑdi ɛvɝ sɛd mæt wɑz hænsəm. hiz dʒʌs dʒɛləs."

Perrin rapped Mat smartly on the top of his head with his knuckles. "Nobody ever said Mat was handsome. He's just jealous."

"ðæts nɑt tʃɹu," mæt sɛd, stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ əbɹʌpli. "mɛɹisə aɪɛlɪn θɪŋks aɪm hænsəm. ʃi toʊl mi soʊ mɔɹ ðən wʌns."

"That's not true," Mat said, straightening abruptly. "Marisa Ayellin thinks I'm handsome. She told me so more than once."

"ɪz mɛɹisə pɹɪɾi?" lɔɪəl æskt.

"Is Marisa pretty?" Loial asked.

"ʃi hæz ə feɪs laɪk ə ɡoʊt," pɛɹɪn sɛd blænli. mæt tʃoʊkt, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡɛɾ ɪz pɹoʊɾɛsts aʊt.

"She has a face like a goat," Perrin said blandly. Mat choked, trying to get his protests out.

ɹænd ɡɹɪn ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɪmsɛlf. mɛɹisə wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz pɹɪɾi əz ɛɡwin. ən ðɪs wɑz ɔlmoʊs laɪk oʊl taɪmz, ɔlmoʊs laɪk biɪŋ bæk hoʊm, bæntɝɪŋ bæk ən fɔɹθ, ən nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ɪn ðə wɝl ðən ə læf ən twɪɾɪŋ ði ʌðɝ fɛloʊ.

Rand grinned in spite of himself. Marisa was almost as pretty as Egwene. And this was almost like old times, almost like being back home, bantering back and forth, and nothing more important in the world than a laugh and twitting the other fellow.

əz ðeɪ meɪd ðɛɹ weɪ θɹu ðə taʊn, oʊɡiɝ ɡɹiɾəd ði ɛldəst, boʊɪŋ əɹ kɝtsiɪŋ, aɪɪŋ ðə hjumən vɪzəɾɝz wɪð ɪntʃɹəst. eɪlɑɹz sɛt feɪs kɛpt ɛniwʌn fɹəm stɑpɪŋ tə spik, ðoʊ. ði oʊnli θɪŋ ðəɾ ɪndəkeɪɾəd wən ðeɪ lɛf ðə taʊn wɑz ði æbsəns ə ðə maʊnz; ðəɹ wɝ stɪl oʊɡiɝ əbaʊt, ɪɡzæmɪnɪŋ tʃɹiz, əɹ səmtaɪmz wɝkɪŋ wɪð pɪtʃ ən sɔ əɹ æks wɛɹ ðəɹ wɝ dɛd lɪmz əɹ wɛɹ ə tʃɹi niɾəd mɔɹ sʌnlaɪt. ðeɪ hændəl ðə tæsks tɛndɝli.

As they made their way through the town, Ogier greeted the Eldest, bowing or curtsying, eyeing the human visitors with interest. Alar's set face kept anyone from stopping to speak, though. The only thing that indicated when they left the town was the absence of the mounds; there were still Ogier about, examining trees, or sometimes working with pitch and saw or axe where there were dead limbs or where a tree needed more sunlight. They handled the tasks tenderly.

dʒun dʒɔɪn ðɛm, liɾɪŋ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz, ən hʊɹɪn keɪm ɹaɪɾɪŋ wɪð ənoʊ ən ði ʌðɝ soʊlʒɝz, ən ðə pækhɔɹsɪz, dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ eɪlɑɹ pɔɪntəɾ ən sɛd, "ɪɾ ɪz oʊvɝ ðɛɹ." ðə bæntɝ daɪd.

Juin joined them, leading their horses, and Hurin came riding with Uno and the other soldiers, and the packhorses, just before Alar pointed and said, "It is over there." The banter died.

ɹænd fɛlt ə moʊməntɛɹi sɝpɹaɪz. ðə weɪɡeɪt hæd tə bi aʊtsaɪd ðə stɛɾɪŋ - ðə weɪz hæd bɪn bɪɡʌn wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ; ðeɪ kəd nɑɾ əv bɪn meɪɾ ɪnsaɪd - bʌt ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə ɪndəkeɪt ðeɪ hæd kɹɔs ðə baʊndɝi. ðən i ɹilaɪz ðəɹ wɑz ə dɪfɝəns; ðə sɛns ə sʌmθɪŋ lɔs ðəɾ i hæd fɛl sɪns ɛntɝɪŋ ðə stɛɾɪŋ wɑz ɡɔn. ðət ɡeɪv ɪm ənʌðɝ sɔɹɾ ə tʃɪl. seɪɾɪn wɑz ðəɹ əɡɛn. weɪɾɪŋ.

Rand felt a momentary surprise. The Waygate had to be Outside the stedding - the Ways had been begun with the One Power; they could not have been made inside - but there was nothing to indicate they had crossed the boundary. Then he realized there was a difference; the sense of something lost that he had felt since entering the stedding was gone. That gave him another sort of chill. Saidin was there again. Waiting.

eɪlɑɹ lɛɾ əm pæst ə tɔl oʊk, ən ðəɹ ɪn ə smɔl klɪɹɪŋ stʊd ðə bɪɡ slæb ə ðə weɪɡeɪt, ðə fɹʌn ʌv ɪt dɛləkətli wɝkt ɪn taɪtli woʊvən vaɪnz ən livz fɹəm ə hʌnʒɹəd dɪfɹən plæns. ɝaʊn ði ɛdʒ ə ðə klɪɹɪŋ ði oʊɡiɝ hæd bɪlt ə loʊ stoʊn koʊpɪŋ ðət simd əz ɪf ɪt hæd ɡɹoʊn ðɛɹ, sədʒɛstɪŋ ə sɝkəl ə ɹuts. ðə lʊk ʌv ɪt meɪd ɹænd ənkʌmftəɹbəl. ɪt tʊk ɪm ə moʊmən tə ɹilaɪz ðət ðə ɹuts sədʒɛstəd wɝ ðoʊz ə bɹæmbəl ən bɹaɪɝ, bɝnɪŋɡlif ən ɪtʃ oʊk. nɑt ðə sɔɹɾ ə plæns ɪndə wɪtʃ ɛniwʌn wəd wɑnə stʌmbəl.

Alar led them past a tall oak, and there in a small clearing stood the big slab of the Waygate, the front of it delicately worked in tightly woven vines and leaves from a hundred different plants. Around the edge of the clearing the Ogier had built a low stone coping that seemed as if it had grown there, suggesting a circle of roots. The look of it made Rand uncomfortable. It took him a moment to realize that the roots suggested were those of bramble and briar, burningleaf and itch oak. Not the sort of plants into which anyone would want to stumble.

ði ɛldəst stɑpt ʃɔɹɾ ə ðə koʊpɪŋ. "ðə wɔl ɪz mɛn tə wɔɹn əweɪ ɛni hu kʌmz hɪɹ. nɑt ðət mɛni ʌv əs du. aɪ maɪsɛlf wɪl nɑt kɹɔs ɪt. bʌt jə meɪ." dʒun dɪd nɑt ɡoʊ əz kloʊs əz ʃi dɪd; hi kɛpt ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz hænz ɑn ðə fɹʌn ə hɪz koʊt, ən wəd nɑt lʊk ət ðə weɪɡeɪt.

The Eldest stopped short of the coping. "The wall is meant to warn away any who comes here. Not that many of us do. I myself will not cross it. But you may." Juin did not go as close as she did; he kept rubbing his hands on the front of his coat, and would not look at the Waygate.

"θæŋk ju," vɛɹɪn toʊl hɝ. "ðə niɾ ɪz ɡɹeɪt, əɹ aɪ wəd nɑɾ əv æskt ɪt."

"Thank you," Verin told her. "The need is great, or I would not have asked it."

ɹænd tɛnst əz ði ɛɛs sədaɪ stɛpt oʊvɝ ðə koʊpɪŋ ən əpɹoʊtʃt ðə weɪɡeɪt. lɔɪəl tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ ən mʌɾɝd tə hɪmsɛlf. ənoʊ ən ðə ɹɛst ə ðə soʊlʒɝz ʃɪftəɾ ɪn ðɛɹ sæɾəlz ən lusən sɔɹdz ɪn ðɛɹ skæbɝdz. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə weɪz əɡɛnst wɪtʃ ə sɔɹd wəd bi ɛni jus, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz sʌmθɪŋ tə kənvɪns ðɛmsɛlvz ðeɪ wɝ ɹɛɾi. oʊnli ɪŋtʃɹ ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sim kɑm; ivən eɪlɑɹ ɡɹɪpt əɹ skɝt wɪð boʊθ hænz.

Rand tensed as the Aes Sedai stepped over the coping and approached the Waygate. Loial took a deep breath and muttered to himself. Uno and the rest of the soldiers shifted in their saddles and loosened swords in their scabbards. There was nothing along the Ways against which a sword would be any use, but it was something to convince themselves they were ready. Only Ingtar and the Aes Sedai seemed calm; even Alar gripped her skirt with both hands.

vɛɹɪn plʌk ði ɑvɛndɪsɔɹə lif, ən ɹænd lin fɔɹwɝɾ ɪntɛnli. hi nu ən ɝdʒ tə əsum ðə vɔɪd, tə bi wɛɹ i kəd ɹitʃ seɪɾɪn ɪf i niɾəd tə.

Verin plucked the Avendesora leaf, and Rand leaned forward intently. He knew an urge to assume the void, to be where he could reach saidin if he needed to.

ðə ɡɹinɝi kɑɹvd əkɹɔs ðə weɪɡeɪt stɝɾ ɪn ən ənfɛl bɹiz, livz flʌɾɝɪŋ əz ə ɡæp oʊpən daʊn ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə mæs ən ðə tu hævz bɪɡæn tə swɪŋ oʊpən.

The greenery carved across the Waygate stirred in an unfelt breeze, leaves fluttering as a gap opened down the center of the mass and the two halves began to swing open.

ɹænd stɛɹɾ ət ðə fɝs kɹæk. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ dʌl, sɪlvɝi ɹəflɛkʃən bɪhaɪn ɪt, oʊnli blæknəs blækɝ ðən pɪtʃ. "kloʊs ɪt!" hi ʃaʊɾəd. "ðə blæk wɪnd! kloʊs ɪt!"

Rand stared at the first crack. There was no dull, silvery reflection behind it, only blackness blacker than pitch. "Close it!" he shouted. "The Black Wind! Close it!"

vɛɹɪn tʊk wʌn stɑɹɾəld lʊk ən θɹʌs ðə θɹi-pɔɪntəd lif bæk ɪn əmʌŋ ɔl ðə vɛɹid livz ɔlɹɛɾi ðɛɹ; ɪt steɪd wən ʃi tʊk əɹ hæn əweɪ ən bæk təwɔɹd ðə koʊpɪŋ. əz sun əz ði ɑvɛndɪsɔɹə lif wɑz bæk ɪn ɪts pleɪs, ðə weɪɡeɪɾ ɪmiɾiətli bɪɡæn tə kloʊz. ðə kɹæk dɪsəpɪɹd, vaɪnz ən livz mɝdʒɪŋ, haɪɾɪŋ ðə blæknəs ə mætʃɪn ʃɪn, ən ðə weɪɡeɪt wɑz oʊnli stoʊn əɡɛn, ɪf stoʊn kɑɹvd ɪn ə nɪɹɝ sɛmbləns ə laɪf ðən sim pɑsəbəl.

Verin took one startled look and thrust the three-pointed leaf back in among all the varied leaves already there; it stayed when she took her hand away and backed toward the coping. As soon as the Avendesora leaf was back in its place, the Waygate immediately began to close. The crack disappeared, vines and leaves merging, hiding the blackness of Machin Shin, and the Waygate was only stone again, if stone carved in a nearer semblance of life than seemed possible.

eɪlɑɹ lɛɾ aʊɾ ə ʃʌɾɝɪŋ bɹɛθ. "mætʃɪn ʃɪn. soʊ kloʊs."

Alar let out a shuddering breath. "Machin Shin. So close."

"ɪt dɪdn tʃɹaɪ tə kʌm aʊt," ɹænd sɛd. dʒun meɪɾ ə stʃɹæŋɡəl saʊnd.

"It didn't try to come out," Rand said. Juin made a strangled sound.

"aɪ hæv toʊl ju," vɛɹɪn sɛd, "ðə blæk wɪn ɪz ə kɹitʃɝ ə ðə weɪz. ɪt kænɑt liv ðɛm." ʃi saʊndəd kɑm, bʌt ʃi stɪl waɪpt əɹ hænz ɑn əɹ skɝt. ɹænd oʊpən ɪz maʊθ, ðən ɡeɪv ɪɾ ʌp. "æn jɛt," ʃi wɛn ɑn, "aɪ wʌndɝ əɾ ɪt biɪŋ hɪɹ. fɝst ɪn kɛɹhin, naʊ hɪɹ. aɪ wʌndɝ." ʃi ɡeɪv ɹænd ə saɪɾɛlɔŋ ɡlæns ðət meɪɾ ɪm dʒʌmp. ðə lʊk wɑz soʊ kwɪk ðəɾ i dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ɛniwʌn ɛls noʊɾəst ɪt, bʌt tə ɹænd ɪt sim tə kənɛkt ɪm wɪð ðə blæk wɪnd.

"I have told you," Verin said, "the Black Wind is a creature of the Ways. It cannot leave them." She sounded calm, but she still wiped her hands on her skirt. Rand opened his mouth, then gave it up. "And yet," she went on, "I wonder at it being here. First in Cairhien, now here. I wonder." She gave Rand a sidelong glance that made him jump. The look was so quick that he did not think anyone else noticed it, but to Rand it seemed to connect him with the Black Wind.

"aɪ hæv nɛvɝ hɝɾ ə ðɪs," eɪlɑɹ sɛd sloʊli, "mætʃɪn ʃɪn weɪɾɪŋ wən ə weɪɡeɪt wɑz oʊpənd. ɪɾ ɔlweɪz ɹoʊm ðə weɪz. bʌɾ ɪts bɪn lɔŋ, ən pɝhæps ðə blæk wɪn hʌŋɝz, ən hoʊps tə kætʃ səm ənwɛɹi wʌn ɛntɝɪŋ ə ɡeɪt. vɛɹɪn, əʃʊɹədli jə kænɑt juz ðɪs weɪɡeɪt. ən haʊɛvɝ ɡɹeɪt jəɹ nid, aɪ kænɑt seɪ aɪm sɑɹi. ðə weɪz bɪlɔŋ tə ðə ʃædoʊ, naʊ."

"I have never heard of this," Alar said slowly, "Machin Shin waiting when a Waygate was opened. It always roamed the Ways. But it has been long, and perhaps the Black Wind hungers, and hopes to catch some unwary one entering a gate. Verin, assuredly you cannot use this Waygate. And however great your need, I cannot say I am sorry. The Ways belong to the Shadow, now."

ɹænd fɹaʊn ət ðə weɪɡeɪt. kəɾ ɪt bi fɑloʊɪŋ mi? ðəɹ wɝ tu mɛni kwɛstʃənz. hæd feɪn sʌmhaʊ ɔɹɾɝd ðə blæk wɪnd? vɛɹɪn sɛɾ ɪt kəd nɑt bi dʌn. ən waɪ wəd feɪn dɪmæn ðəɾ i fɑloʊ, ðən tʃɹaɪ tə stɑp hɪm? hi oʊnli nu ðəɾ i bɪliv ðə mɛsədʒ. hi hæd tə ɡoʊ tə toʊmən hɛd. ɪf ðeɪ faʊn ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ ən mæts dæɡɝ ʌndɝ ə bʊʃ təmɑɹoʊ, hi stɪl hæd tə ɡoʊ.

Rand frowned at the Waygate. Could it be following me? There were too many questions. Had Fain somehow ordered the Black Wind? Verin said it could not be done. And why would Fain demand that he follow, then try to stop him? He only knew that he believed the message. He had to go to Toman Head. If they found the Horn of Valere and Mat's dagger under a bush tomorrow, he still had to go.

vɛɹɪn stʊd wɪð aɪz ənfoʊkəst ɪn θɔt. mæt wɑz sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə koʊpɪŋ wɪð ɪz hɛɾ ɪn ɪz hænz, ən pɛɹɪn wɑtʃt ɪm wɝidli. lɔɪəl simd ɹɪliv ðət ðeɪ kəd nɑt juz ðə weɪɡeɪt, ən əʃeɪmd ət biɪŋ ɹɪlivd.

Verin stood with eyes unfocused in thought. Mat was sitting on the coping with his head in his hands, and Perrin watched him worriedly. Loial seemed relieved that they could not use the Waygate, and ashamed at being relieved.

"wi ɑɹ dʌn fəɹ hɪɹ," ɪŋtʃɹ ənaʊnst. "vɛɹɪn sədaɪ, aɪ fɑloʊd jə hɪɹ əɡɛns maɪ bɛɾɝ dʒʌdʒmənt, bʌɾ aɪ kən noʊ lɔŋɡɝ fɑloʊ. aɪ min tə ɹɪtɝn tə kɛɹhin. bɑɹθeɪnz kən tɛl mi wɛɹ ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz wɛnt, ən sʌmhaʊ əl meɪk ɪm də ɪt."

"We are done for here," Ingtar announced. "Verin Sedai, I followed you here against my better judgment, but I can no longer follow. I mean to return to Cairhien. Barthanes can tell me where the Darkfriends went, and somehow I will make him do it."

"feɪn wɛn tə toʊmən hɛd," ɹænd sɛd wɛɹəli. "ænd wɛɹ i wɛnt, ðæts wɛɹ ðə hɔɹn ɪz, ən ðə dæɡɝ."

"Fain went to Toman Head," Rand said wearily. "And where he went, that's where the Horn is, and the dagger."

"aɪ səpoʊz. . . ." pɛɹɪn ʃɹʌɡd ɹɪlʌktənli. "aɪ səpoʊz wi kəd tʃɹaɪ ənʌðɝ weɪɡeɪt. əɾ ənʌðɝ stɛɾɪŋ?"

"I suppose. . . ." Perrin shrugged reluctantly. "I suppose we could try another Waygate. At another stedding?"

lɔɪəl stʃɹoʊkt ɪz tʃɪn ən spoʊk kwɪkli, əz ɪf tə meɪk ʌp fəɹ ɪz ɹɪlif ət ðə feɪljɝ hɪɹ. "stɛɾɪŋ kæntwn laɪz dʒʌst əbʌv ðə ɹɪvɝ aɪɹælɛl, ən stɛɾɪŋ teɪaɪdʒɪŋ ɪz ist ʌv ɪɾ ɪn ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝld. bʌt ðə weɪɡeɪɾ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, wɛɹ ðə ɡɹoʊv wɑz, ɪz kloʊsɝ, ən ðə ɡeɪɾ ɪn ðə ɡɹoʊv ət tɑɹ vəlɑn ɪz kloʊsəst ʌv ɔl."

Loial stroked his chin and spoke quickly, as if to make up for his relief at the failure here. "Stedding Cantoine lies just above the River Iralell, and Stedding Taijing is east of it in the Spine of the World. But the Waygate in Caemlyn, where the grove was, is closer, and the gate in the grove at Tar Valon is closest of all."

"wɪtʃɛvɝ weɪɡeɪt wi tʃɹaɪ tə juz," vɛɹɪn sɛɾ æbsənli, "aɪ fɪɹ wɪl faɪn mætʃɪn ʃɪn weɪɾɪŋ." eɪlɑɹ lʊkt əɾ əɹ kwɛstʃənɪŋli, bʌt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛd noʊ mɔɹ ðəɾ ɛniwʌn kəd hɪɹ. ʃi mʌɾɝd tə hɝsɛlf ɪnstɛd, ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛɾ əz ɪf ɑɹɡjuɪŋ wɪð hɝsɛlf.

"Whichever Waygate we try to use," Verin said absently, "I fear we will find Machin Shin waiting." Alar looked at her questioningly, but the Aes Sedai said no more that anyone could hear. She muttered to herself instead, shaking her head as if arguing with herself.

"wʌt wi nid," hʊɹɪn sɛd dɪfəɾəntli, "ɪz wʌn ə ðoʊz pɔɹɾəl stoʊnz." hi lʊk tə eɪlɑɹ, ðən vɛɹɪn, ən wən niðɝ toʊld ɪm tə stɑp, hi wɛn ɑn, saʊndɪŋ ɪnkɹisɪŋli kɑnfəɾənt. "ðə leɪɾi səlin sɛd ðoʊz oʊld ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd stʌɾid ðoʊz wɝlz, ən ðət wɑz haʊ ðeɪ nu haʊ tə meɪk ðə weɪz. ən ðət pleɪs wi wɝ . . . wɛl, ɪɾ oʊnli tʊk əs tu deɪz - lɛs - tə tʃɹævəl ə hʌnʒɹəd liɡz. ɪf wi kəd juz ə pɔɹɾəl stoʊn tə ɡoʊ tə ðət wɝld, əɹ wʌn laɪk ɪt, waɪ, ɪɾəd teɪk noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə wik əɹ tu tə ɹitʃ ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən, ən wi kəd kʌm bæk ɹaɪɾ ɑn toʊmən hɛd. meɪbi ɪɾ ɪzən soʊ kwɪk əz ðə weɪz, bʌɾ ɪts ə lɔŋ saɪt kwɪkɝ ðən ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɔf wɛst. wʌt dʒju seɪ, lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹ? lɔɹd ɹænd?"

"What we need," Hurin said diffidently, "is one of those Portal Stones." He looked to Alar, then Verin, and when neither told him to stop, he went on, sounding increasingly confident. "The Lady Selene said those old Aes Sedai had studied those worlds, and that was how they knew how to make the Ways. And that place we were . . . well, it only took us two days - less - to travel a hundred leagues. If we could use a Portal Stone to go to that world, or one like it, why, it'd take no more than a week or two to reach the Aryth Ocean, and we could come back right on Toman Head. Maybe it isn't so quick as the Ways, but it's a long sight quicker than riding off west. What do you say, Lord Ingtar? Lord Rand?"

vɛɹɪn ænsɝd hɪm. "wʌt jə sədʒɛs maɪt bi pɑsəbəl, snɪfɝ, bʌɾ əz wɛl hoʊp tə oʊpən ðɪs weɪɡeɪɾ əɡɛn ən faɪn mætʃɪn ʃɪn ɡɔn əz hoʊp tə faɪn ə pɔɹɾəl stoʊn. aɪ noʊ nʌn kloʊsɝ ðən ði il weɪst. ðoʊ wi kəd ɡoʊ bæk ɪndə kɪnsleɪɝz dæɡɝ, ɪf ju, əɹ ɹænd, əɹ lɔɪəl θɪŋk jə kəd faɪn ðət stoʊn əɡɛn."

Verin answered him. "What you suggest might be possible, sniffer, but as well hope to open this Waygate again and find Machin Shin gone as hope to find a Portal Stone. I know none closer than the Aiel Waste. Though we could go back into Kinslayer's Dagger, if you, or Rand, or Loial think you could find that Stone again."

ɹænd lʊkt ət mæt. hɪz fɹɛn hæd lɪftəɾ ɪz hɛd hoʊpfəli ət ðɪs tɔk ə ðə stoʊnz. ə fju wiks, vɛɹɪn hæd sɛd. ɪf ðeɪ sɪmpli ɹoʊd wɛst, mæt wəd nɛvɝ lɪv tə si toʊmən hɛd.

Rand looked at Mat. His friend had lifted his head hopefully at this talk of the Stones. A few weeks, Verin had said. If they simply rode west, Mat would never live to see Toman Head.

"aɪ kən faɪn ɪt," ɹænd sɛd ɹɪlʌktənli. hi fɛlt əʃeɪmd. mæts ɡoʊɪŋ tə daɪ, dɑɹkfɹɛnz əv ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ, feɪn wɪl hɝɾ ɛmənz fild ɪf jə doʊn fɑloʊ hɪm, ən jəɹ əfɹeɪd tə tʃænəl ðə paʊɝ. wʌns tə ɡoʊ ən wʌns tə kʌm bæk. twaɪs mɔɹ woʊn dʒɹaɪv jə mæd. wʌt ɹɪli meɪɾ ɪm əfɹeɪd, ðoʊ, wɑz ði iɡɝnəs ðət lɛpt ɪnsaɪɾ ɪm ət ðə θɔɾ ə tʃænəlɪŋ əɡɛn, ʌv filɪŋ ðə paʊɝ fɪl hɪm, ʌv filɪŋ tʃɹuli əlaɪv.

"I can find it," Rand said reluctantly. He felt ashamed. Mat's going to die, Darkfriends have the Horn of Valere, Fain will hurt Emond's Field if you don't follow him, and you're afraid to channel the Power. Once to go and once to come back. Twice more won't drive you mad. What really made him afraid, though, was the eagerness that leaped inside him at the thought of channeling again, of feeling the Power fill him, of feeling truly alive.

"aɪ də nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ðɪs," eɪlɑɹ sɛd sloʊli. "ðə pɔɹɾəl stoʊnz əv nɑt bɪn juz sɪns ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz. aɪ dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ðəɹ wɑz ɛniwʌn u stɪl nu haʊ tə juz ðɛm."

"I do not understand this," Alar said slowly. "The Portal Stones have not been used since the Age of Legends. I did not think there was anyone who still knew how to use them."

"ðə bɹaʊn ədʒɑ noʊz mɛni θɪŋz," vɛɹɪn sɛd dʒɹaɪli, "æn aɪ noʊ haʊ ðə stoʊnz meɪ bi juzd."

"The Brown Ajah knows many things," Verin said dryly, "and I know how the Stones may be used."

ði ɛldəs nɑɾəd. "tʃɹuli ðəɹ ɑɹ wʌndɝz ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ ʌv wɪtʃ wi də nɑt dʒɹim. bʌɾ ɪf jə kən juz ə pɔɹɾəl stoʊn, ðəɹ ɪz noʊ nid fəɹ jə tə ɹaɪd tə kɪnsleɪɝz dæɡɝ. ðəɹ ɪz ə stoʊn nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm wɛɹ wi stænd."

The Eldest nodded. "Truly there are wonders in the White Tower of which we do not dream. But if you can use a Portal Stone, there is no need for you to ride to Kinslayer's Dagger. There is a Stone not far from where we stand."

"ðə wil wivz əz ðə wil wɪlz, ən ðə pæɾɝn pɹəvaɪdz wʌɾ ɪz nidfəl." ði æbsən lʊk dʒɹɑp fɹəm vɛɹɪnz feɪs ɔltəɡɛðɝ. "teɪk əs tə ɪt," ʃi sɛd bɹɪskli. "wi hæv lɔs mɔɹ ðən ɪnʌf taɪm ɔlɹɛɾi."

"The Wheel weaves as the Wheel wills, and the Pattern provides what is needful." The absent look dropped from Verin's face altogether. "Take us to it," she said briskly. "We have lost more than enough time already."


tʃæptɝ θɝɾisɛvən


CHAPTER 37

wʌt maɪt bi


What Might Be

eɪlɑɹ lɛɾ əm əweɪ fɹəm ðə weɪɡeɪɾ əɾ ə dɪɡnəfaɪd peɪs, ðoʊ dʒun simd mɔɹ ðən æŋkʃəs tə liv ðə weɪɡeɪt bɪhaɪnd. mæt, ət list, lʊkt əhɛɾ iɡɝli, ən hʊɹɪn sim kɑnfəɾənt, waɪl lɔɪəl əpɪɹd kənsɝn mɔɹ ðəɾ eɪlɑɹ maɪt tʃeɪnʒ əɹ maɪn əbaʊɾ ɪz ɡoʊɪŋ ðən əbaʊɾ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls. ɹænd dɪd nɑt hɝi əz i pʊld ɹɛɾ əlɔŋ baɪ ðə ɹeɪnz. hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk vɛɹɪn mɛn tə juz ðə stoʊn hɝsɛlf.

Alar led them away from the Waygate at a dignified pace, though Juin seemed more than anxious to leave the Waygate behind. Mat, at least, looked ahead eagerly, and Hurin seemed confident, while Loial appeared concerned more that Alar might change her mind about his going than about anything else. Rand did not hurry as he pulled Red along by the reins. He did not think Verin meant to use the Stone herself.

ðə ɡɹeɪ stoʊn kɑləm stʊɾ əpɹaɪt nɪɹ ə bitʃ ɔlmoʊst ə hʌnʒɹəd fit tɔl ən fɔɹ peɪsɪz θɪk; ɹænd wʊɾə θɔɾ ɪɾ ə bɪɡ tʃɹi bɪfɔɹ i sɔ ðə ɡɹeɪt tʃɹiz. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ wɔɹnɪŋ koʊpɪŋ hɪɹ, oʊnli ə fju waɪldflaʊɹz pʊʃɪŋ θɹu ðə lifi mʌltʃ ə ðə fɔɹəs flɔɹ. ðə pɔɹɾəl stoʊn ɪtsɛlf wɑz wɛðɝd, bʌt ðə sɪmbəlz kʌvɝɪŋ ɪt wɝ stɪl klɪɹ ɪnʌf tə meɪk aʊt.

The gray stone column stood upright near a beech almost a hundred feet tall and four paces thick; Rand would have thought it a big tree before he saw the Great Trees. There was no warning coping here, only a few wildflowers pushing through the leafy mulch of the forest floor. The Portal Stone itself was weathered, but the symbols covering it were still clear enough to make out.

ðə maʊntəd ʃaɪnɝən soʊlʒɝz spɹɛɾ aʊɾ ɪn ə lus sɝkəl ɝaʊn ðə stoʊn ən ðoʊz əfʊt.

The mounted Shienaran soldiers spread out in a loose circle around the Stone and those afoot.

"wi stʊɾ ɪɾ əpɹaɪt," eɪlɑɹ sɛd, "wɛn wi faʊn ɪt mɛni jɪɹz əɡoʊ, bʌt wi dɪd nɑt muv ɪt. ɪt . . . sim tə . . . ɹɪzɪs biɪŋ muvd." ʃi wɛn ɹaɪɾ ʌp tə ɪt, ən leɪɾ ə bɪɡ hæn ɑn ðə stoʊn. "aɪ hæv ɔlweɪz θɔɾ ʌv ɪɾ əz ə sɪmbəl ʌv wʌɾ əz bɪn lɔst, wʌɾ əz bɪn fɝɡɑɾən. ɪn ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz, ɪt kəd bi stʌɾid ən sʌmwʌɾ ʌndɝstʊd. tə ʌs, ɪts oʊnli stoʊn."

"We stood it upright," Alar said, "when we found it many years ago, but we did not move it. It . . . seemed to . . . resist being moved." She went right up to it, and laid a big hand on the Stone. "I have always thought of it as a symbol of what has been lost, what has been forgotten. In the Age of Legends, it could be studied and somewhat understood. To us, it is only stone."

"mɔɹ ðən ðæt, aɪ hoʊp." vɛɹɪnz vɔɪs ɡɹu bɹɪskɝ. "ɛldəst, aɪ θæŋk jə fəɹ jəɹ hɛlp. fɝɡɪv əs fəɹ əɹ læk ə sɛɹəmoʊni ɪn livɪŋ ju, bʌt ðə wil weɪts fəɹ noʊ wʊmən. ət list wɪl noʊ lɔŋɡɝ dɪstɝb ðə pis ə jəɹ stɛɾɪŋ."

"More than that, I hope." Verin's voice grew brisker. "Eldest, I thank you for your help. Forgive us for our lack of ceremony in leaving you, but the Wheel waits for no woman. At least we will no longer disturb the peace of your stedding."

"wi kɔl ðə stoʊnmeɪsɑnz bæk fɹəm kɛɹhin," eɪlɑɹ sɛd, "bʌt wi stɪl hɪɹ wʌt hæpənz ɪn ðə wɝld aʊtsaɪd. fɔls dʒɹæɡənz. ðə ɡɹeɪt hʌn ə ðə hɔɹn. wi hɪɹ, ən ɪt pæsəz əs baɪ. aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk tɑɹmən ɡdən wɪl pæs əs baɪ, əɹ liv əs ɪn pis. fɛɹ jə wɛl, vɛɹɪn sədaɪ. ɔl ə ju, fɛɹ wɛl, ən meɪ jə ʃɛltɝ ɪn ðə pɑm ə ðə kɹieɪɾɝz hænd. dʒun." ʃi pɔzd oʊnli fəɹ ə ɡlæns ət lɔɪəl ən ə læst ædmənətɔɹi lʊk ət ɹænd, ən ðən ði oʊɡiɝ wɝ ɡɔn əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz.

"We called the stonemasons back from Cairhien," Alar said, "but we still hear what happens in the world Outside. False Dragons. The Great Hunt of the Horn. We hear, and it passes us by. I do not think Tarmon Gai'don will pass us by, or leave us in peace. Fare you well, Verin Sedai. All of you, fare well, and may you shelter in the palm of the Creator's hand. Juin." She paused only for a glance at Loial and a last admonitory look at Rand, and then the Ogier were gone among the trees.

ðəɹ wɑz ə kɹikɪŋ ə sæɾəlz əz ðə soʊlʒɝz ʃɪftəd. ɪŋtʃɹ lʊkt ɝaʊn ðə sɝkəl ðeɪ meɪd. "ɪz ðɪs nɛsəsɛɹi, vɛɹɪn sədaɪ? ivən ɪf ɪt kən bi dʌn. . . . wi də nɑɾ ivən noʊ ɪf ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz ɹɪli hæv teɪkən ðə hɔɹn tə toʊmən hɛd. aɪ stɪl bɪliv aɪ kən meɪk bɑɹθeɪnz - "

There was a creaking of saddles as the soldiers shifted. Ingtar looked around the circle they made. "Is this necessary, Verin Sedai? Even if it can be done. . . . We do not even know if the Darkfriends really have taken the Horn to Toman Head. I still believe I can make Barthanes - "

"ɪf wi kænɑt bi ʃʊɹ," vɛɹɪn sɛd maɪldli, kʌɾɪŋ ɪm ɔf, "ðɛn toʊmən hɛɾ ɪz əz ɡʊɾ ə pleɪs tə lʊk əz ɛni ʌðɝ. mɔɹ ðən wʌns aɪv hɝd jə seɪ jə wəd ɹaɪd tə ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl ɪf nid bi tə ɹɪkʌvɝ ðə hɔɹn. dʒju hoʊl bæk naʊ, ət ðɪs?" ʃi dʒɛstʃɝd tə ðə stoʊn ʌndɝ ðə smuð-bɑɹk tʃɹi.

"If we cannot be sure," Verin said mildly, cutting him off, "then Toman Head is as good a place to look as any other. More than once I've heard you say you would ride to Shayol Ghul if need be to recover the Horn. Do you hold back now, at this?" She gestured to the Stone under the smooth-barked tree.

ɪŋtʃɹz bæk stɪfənd. "aɪ hoʊl bæk ət nʌθɪŋ. teɪk əs tə toʊmən hɛɾ əɹ teɪk əs tə ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl. ɪf ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ laɪz ət ði ɛnd, əl fɑloʊ ju."

Ingtar's back stiffened. "I hold back at nothing. Take us to Toman Head or take us to Shayol Ghul. If the Horn of Valere lies at the end, I will follow you."

"ðæɾ ɪz wɛl, ɪŋtʃɹ. naʊ, ɹænd, juv bɪn tʃɹænspɔɹɾəd baɪ ə pɔɹɾəl stoʊn mɔɹ ɹisənli ðən aɪ. kʌm." ʃi moʊʃən tə hɪm, ən i lɛd ɹɛɾ oʊvɝ tə hɝ ət ðə stoʊn.

"That is well, Ingtar. Now, Rand, you have been transported by a Portal Stone more recently than I. Come." She motioned to him, and he led Red over to her at the Stone.

"juv juzd ə pɔɹɾəl stoʊn?" hi ɡlænst oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ tə meɪk ʃʊɹ noʊ wʌn ɛls wɑz kloʊs ɪnʌf tə hɪɹ. "ðɛn jə doʊn min fəɹ mi tə." hi ɡeɪv ə ɹɪlivd ʃɹʌɡ.

"You've used a Portal Stone?" He glanced over his shoulder to make sure no one else was close enough to hear. "Then you don't mean for me to." He gave a relieved shrug.

vɛɹɪn lʊkt əɾ ɪm blænli. "aɪ hæv nɛvɝ juzd ə stoʊn; ðəɾ ɪz waɪ jəɹ jus ɪz mɔɹ ɹisən ðən maɪn. aɪm wɛl əwɛɹ ə maɪ lɪməts. aɪ wəd bi dɪstʃɹɔɪd bɪfɔɹ aɪ keɪm kloʊs tə tʃænəlɪŋ ɪnʌf paʊɝ tə wɝk ə pɔɹɾəl stoʊn. bʌɾ aɪ noʊ ə lɪɾəl ə ðɛm. ɪnʌf tə hɛlp ju, ə bɪt."

Verin looked at him blandly. "I have never used a Stone; that is why your use is more recent than mine. I am well aware of my limits. I would be destroyed before I came close to channeling enough Power to work a Portal Stone. But I know a little of them. Enough to help you, a bit."

"bʌɾ aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɛniθɪŋ." hi lɛɾ ɪz hɔɹs ɝaʊn ðə stoʊn, lʊkɪŋ ɪɾ ʌp ən daʊn. "ðə wʌn θɪŋ aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɪz ðə sɪmbəl fəɹ əɹ wɝld. səlin ʃoʊd mi, bʌɾ aɪ doʊn si ɪt hɪɹ."

"But I don't know anything." He led his horse around the Stone, looking it up and down. "The one thing I remember is the symbol for our world. Selene showed me, but I don't see it here."

"ʌv kɔɹs nɑt. nɑɾ ɑn ə stoʊn ɪn əɹ wɝld; ðə sɪmbəlz ɑɹ eɪdz ɪn ɡɛɾɪŋ tə ə wɝld." ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "wʌt wəɾ aɪ nɑt ɡɪv tə tɔk wɪð ðɪs ɡɝl ə jʊɹz? əɹ bɛɾɝ, tə pʊt maɪ hænz ɑn əɹ bʊk. ɪts dʒɛnɝəli θɔt ðət noʊ kɑpi ʌv mɪɹɝz ə ðə wil sɝvaɪv ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ hoʊl. sɹəfɛl ɔlweɪz tɛlz mi ðəɹ ɑɹ mɔɹ bʊks ðət wi bɪliv lɔs ðən aɪ kəd kɹɛɾət weɪɾɪŋ tə bi faʊnd. wɛl, noʊ jus ɪn wɝiɪŋ oʊvɝ wʌɾ aɪ doʊnt noʊ. aɪ də noʊ səm θɪŋz. ðə sɪmbəlz ɑn ðə tɑp hæf ə ðə stoʊn stæn fəɹ wɝlz. nɑɾ ɔl ðə wɝlz ðət maɪt bi, ʌv kɔɹs. əpɛɹənli, nɑɾ ɛvɹi stoʊn kənɛks tə ɛvɹi wɝld, ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌv ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz bɪliv ðət ðəɹ wɝ pɑsəbəl wɝlz noʊ stoʊnz əɾ ɔl tʌtʃt. dʒju si nʌθɪŋ ðət spɑɹks ə mɛmɹi?"

"Of course not. Not on a Stone in our world; the symbols are aids in getting to a world." She shook her head. "What would I not give to talk with this girl of yours? Or better, to put my hands on her book. It is generally thought that no copy of Mirrors of the Wheel survived the Breaking whole. Serafelle always tells me there are more books that we believe lost than I could credit waiting to be found. Well, no use in worrying over what I don't know. I do know some things. The symbols on the top half of the Stone stand for worlds. Not all the Worlds That Might Be, of course. Apparently, not every Stone connects to every world, and the Aes Sedai of the Age of Legends believed that there were possible worlds no Stones at all touched. Do you see nothing that sparks a memory?"

"nʌθɪŋ." ɪf i faʊn ðə ɹaɪt sɪmbəl, hi kəd juz ɪt tə faɪn feɪn ən ðə hɔɹn, tə seɪv mæt, tə stɑp feɪn hɝɾɪŋ ɛmənz fild. ɪf i faʊn ðə sɪmbəl, hi wəɾ əv tə tʌtʃ seɪɾɪn. hi wɑntəd tə seɪv mæt ən stɑp feɪn, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt wɑnə tʌtʃ seɪɾɪn. hi wɑz əfɹeɪd tə tʃænəl, ən i hʌŋɡɝd fəɹ ɪt laɪk ə stɑɹvɪŋ mæn fəɹ fud. "aɪ doʊn ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɛniθɪŋ."

"Nothing." If he found the right symbol, he could use it to find Fain and the Horn, to save Mat, to stop Fain hurting Emond's Field. If he found the symbol, he would have to touch saidin. He wanted to save Mat and stop Fain, but he did not want to touch saidin. He was afraid to channel, and he hungered for it like a starving man for food. "I don't remember anything."

vɛɹɪn saɪd. "ðə sɪmbəlz ət ðə bɑɾəm ɪndəkeɪt stoʊnz əɾ ʌðɝ pleɪsəz. ɪf jə noʊ ðə tʃɹɪk ʌv ɪt, jə kəd teɪk ʌs, nɑt tə ðɪs seɪm stoʊn ɪn ənʌðɝ wɝld, bʌt tə wʌn ə ðoʊz ʌðɝz ðɛɹ, əɹ ivən tə wʌn ə ðɛm hɪɹ. ɪt wɑz sʌmθɪŋ əkɪn tə tʃɹævlɪŋ, aɪ θɪŋk, bʌt dʒʌst əz noʊ wʌn ɹɪmɛmbɝz haʊ tə tʃɹævəl, noʊ wʌn ɹɪmɛmbɝz ðə tʃɹɪk. wɪθaʊt ðət nɑlədʒ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ ɪt maɪɾ izəli dɪstʃɹɔɪ əs ɔl." ʃi pɔɪntəd tə tu pɛɹəlɛl weɪvi laɪnz kɹɔs baɪ ən ɑd skwɪɡəl, kɑɹv loʊ ɑn ðə kɑləm. "ðæɾ ɪndəkeɪts ə stoʊn ɑn toʊmən hɛd. ɪts wʌn ə θɹi stoʊnz fəɹ wɪtʃ aɪ noʊ ðə sɪmbəl; ði oʊnli wʌn ə ðoʊz θɹi aɪv vɪzəɾəd. ən wʌɾ aɪ lɝnd - æftɝ nɪɹli biɪŋ kɑt baɪ ðə snoʊz ɪn ðə maʊntənz ə mɪst ən fɹizɪŋ maɪ weɪ əkɹɔs ɑlməθ pleɪn - wɑz æbsəlutli nʌθɪŋ. dʒju pleɪ ət daɪs, əɹ kɑɹdz, ɹænd ælθɹ?"

Verin sighed. "The symbols at the bottom indicate Stones at other places. If you know the trick of it, you could take us, not to this same Stone in another world, but to one of those others there, or even to one of them here. It was something akin to Traveling, I think, but just as no one remembers how to Travel, no one remembers the trick. Without that knowledge, trying it might easily destroy us all." She pointed to two parallel wavy lines crossed by an odd squiggle, carved low on the column. "That indicates a Stone on Toman Head. It is one of three Stones for which I know the symbol; the only one of those three I've visited. And what I learned - after nearly being caught by the snows in the Mountains of Mist and freezing my way across Almoth Plain - was absolutely nothing. Do you play at dice, or cards, Rand al'Thor?"

"mæts ðə ɡæmblɝ. waɪ?"

"Mat's the gambler. Why?"

"jɛs. wɛl, wɪl liv ɪm aʊɾ ə ðɪs, aɪ θɪŋk. ðiz ʌðɝ sɪmbəlz ɑɹ ɔlsoʊ noʊn tə mi."

"Yes. Well, we'll leave him out of this, I think. These other symbols are also known to me."

wɪð wʌn fɪŋɡɝ ʃi aʊtlaɪn ə ɹɛktæŋɡəl kənteɪnɪŋ eɪt kɑɹvɪŋz ðət wɝ mʌtʃ əlaɪk, ə sɝkəl ən ən æɹoʊ, bʌɾ ɪn hæf ði æɹoʊ wɑz kənteɪn ɪnsaɪd ðə sɝkəl, waɪl ɪn ði ʌðɝz ðə pɔɪn pɪɹs ðə sɝkəl θɹu. ði æɹoʊz pɔɪntəd lɛft, ɹaɪt, ʌp ən daʊn, ən sɝaʊndɪŋ itʃ sɝkəl wɑz ə dɪfɹən laɪn ʌv wʌt ɹænd wɑz ʃʊɹ wɑz skɹɪpt, ðoʊ ɪn noʊ læŋɡwədʒ i nu, ɔl kɝvɪŋ laɪnz ðət sʌɾənli bɪkeɪm dʒæɡd hʊks, ðən floʊɾ ɑn əɡɛn.

With one finger she outlined a rectangle containing eight carvings that were much alike, a circle and an arrow, but in half the arrow was contained inside the circle, while in the others the point pierced the circle through. The arrows pointed left, right, up and down, and surrounding each circle was a different line of what Rand was sure was script, though in no language he knew, all curving lines that suddenly became jagged hooks, then flowed on again.

"æt list," vɛɹɪn wɛn ɑn, "aɪ noʊ ðɪs mʌtʃ əbaʊt ðɛm. itʃ stænz fəɹ ə wɝld, ðə stʌɾi ʌv wɪtʃ lɛɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli tə ðə meɪkɪŋ ə ðə weɪz. ðiz ɑɹ nɑɾ ɔl ə ðə wɝlz stʌɾid, bʌt ði oʊnli wʌnz fəɹ wɪtʃ aɪ noʊ ðə sɪmbəlz. ðɪs ɪz wɛɹ ɡæmbəlɪŋ kʌmz ɪn. aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌɾ ɛni ʌv ðiz wɝlz ɪz laɪk. ɪts bɪliv ðəɹ ɑɹ wɝlz wɛɹ ə jɪɹ ɪz oʊnli ə deɪ hɪɹ, ən ʌðɝz wɛɹ ə deɪ ɪz ə jɪɹ hɪɹ. ðəɹ ɑɹ səpoʊz tə bi wɝlz wɛɹ ðə vɛɹi ɛɹ wəd kɪl əs əɾ ə bɹɛθ, ən wɝlz ðət bɛɹli hæv ɪnʌf ɹiæləɾi tə hoʊl təɡɛðɝ. aɪ wəd nɑt spɛkjəleɪɾ ɑn wʌt maɪt hæpən ɪf wi faʊn aʊɝsɛlvz ɪn wʌn ə ðoʊz. jə mʌs tʃuz. əz maɪ fɑðɝ wəɾ əv sɛd, ɪts taɪm tə ɹoʊl ðə daɪs."

"At least," Verin went on, "I know this much about them. Each stands for a world, the study of which led eventually to the making of the Ways. These are not all of the worlds studied, but the only ones for which I know the symbols. This is where gambling comes in. I don't know what any of these worlds is like. It is believed there are worlds where a year is only a day here, and others where a day is a year here. There are supposed to be worlds where the very air would kill us at a breath, and worlds that barely have enough reality to hold together. I would not speculate on what might happen if we found ourselves in one of those. You must choose. As my father would have said, it's time to roll the dice."

ɹænd stɛɹd, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd. "aɪ kəd kɪl ɔl ʌv ʌs, wʌtɛvɝ aɪ tʃuz."

Rand stared, shaking his head. "I could kill all of us, whatever I choose."

"ɑɹ jə nɑt wɪlɪŋ tə teɪk ðət ɹɪsk? fəɹ ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ? fəɹ mæt?"

"Are you not willing to take that risk? For the Horn of Valere? For Mat?"

"waɪ ɑɹ jə soʊ wɪlɪŋ tə teɪk ɪt? aɪ doʊn ivən noʊ ɪf aɪ kən də ɪt. ɪt - ɪt dʌznt wɝk ɛvɹi taɪm aɪ tʃɹaɪ." hi nu noʊ wʌn hæd kʌm ɛni kloʊsɝ, bʌɾ i lʊkt ɛniweɪ. ɔl ə ðɛm weɪɾəd ɪn ə lus sɝkəl ɝaʊn ðə stoʊn, wɑtʃɪŋ, bʌt nɑt kloʊs ɪnʌf tə ivzdʒɹɑp. "səmtaɪmz seɪɾɪn ɪz dʒʌs ðɛɹ. aɪ kən fil ɪt, bʌɾ ɪt maɪɾ əz wɛl bi ɑn ðə mun əz fɑɹ əz tʌtʃɪŋ ɪt. ən ivən ɪf ɪt dʌz wɝk, wʌɾ ɪf aɪ teɪk əs sʌmpleɪs wi kæn bɹið? wʌt ɡʊd wɪl ðət də mæt? əɹ ðə hɔɹn?"

"Why are you so willing to take it? I don't even know if I can do it. It - it doesn't work every time I try." He knew no one had come any closer, but he looked anyway. All of them waited in a loose circle around the Stone, watching, but not close enough to eavesdrop. "Sometimes saidin is just there. I can feel it, but it might as well be on the moon as far as touching it. And even if it does work, what if I take us someplace we can't breathe? What good will that do Mat? Or the Horn?"

"ju ɑɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn," ʃi sɛd kwaɪətli. "oʊ, jə kən daɪ, bʌɾ aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðə pæɾɝn wɪl lɛt jə daɪ əntɪl ɪts dʌn wɪð ju. ðən əɡɛn, ðə ʃædoʊ laɪz ɑn ðə pæɾɝn, naʊ, ən u kən seɪ haʊ ðəɾ əfɛks ðə wivɪŋ? ɔl jə kən də ɪz fɑloʊ jəɹ dɛstəni."

"You are the Dragon Reborn," she said quietly. "Oh, you can die, but I don't think the Pattern will let you die until it is done with you. Then again, the Shadow lies on the Pattern, now, and who can say how that affects the weaving? All you can do is follow your destiny."

"aɪ æm ɹænd ælθɹ," hi ɡɹaʊld. "aɪ æm nɑt ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. aɪ woʊn bi ə fɔls dʒɹæɡən."

"I am Rand al'Thor," he growled. "I am not the Dragon Reborn. I won't be a false Dragon."

"ju ɑɹ wʌt jə ɑɹ. wɪl jə tʃuz, əɹ wɪl jə stæn hɪɹ əntɪl jəɹ fɹɛn daɪz?"

"You are what you are. Will you choose, or will you stand here until your friend dies?"

ɹænd hɝɾ ɪz tiθ ɡɹaɪndɪŋ ən fɔɹs hɪmsɛlf tə ənklɛntʃ ɪz dʒɔ. ðə sɪmbəlz kəɾ ɔl əv bɪn ɪɡzækli əlaɪk, fəɹ ɔl ðeɪ mɛn tə hɪm. ðə skɹɪp kəɾ əz wɛl əv bɪn ə tʃɪkənz skɹætʃɪŋz. ət læst i sɛɾəld ɑn wʌn, wɪð ən æɹoʊ pɔɪntɪŋ lɛf kəz ɪt pɔɪntəd təwɔɹd toʊmən hɛd, ən æɹoʊ ðət pɪɹs ðə sɝkəl kəz ɪt hæd bɹoʊkən fɹi, əz i wɑntəd tə. hi wɑntəd tə læf. sətʃ smɔl θɪŋz ɑn wɪtʃ tə ɡæmbəl ɔl ðɛɹ laɪvz.

Rand heard his teeth grinding and forced himself to unclench his jaw. The symbols could all have been exactly alike, for all they meant to him. The script could as well have been a chicken's scratchings. At last he settled on one, with an arrow pointing left because it pointed toward Toman Head, an arrow that pierced the circle because it had broken free, as he wanted to. He wanted to laugh. Such small things on which to gamble all their lives.

"kʌm kloʊsɝ," vɛɹɪn ɔɹɾɝd ði ʌðɝz. "ɪt wɪl bi bɛst ɪf jə ɑɹ nɪɹ." ðeɪ oʊbeɪd, wɪð oʊnli ə lɪɾəl hɛzəteɪʃən. "ɪɾ ɪz taɪm tə bɪɡɪn," ʃi sɛɾ əz ðeɪ ɡæðɝd ɹaʊnd.

"Come closer," Verin ordered the others. "It will be best if you are near." They obeyed, with only a little hesitation. "It is time to begin," she said as they gathered round.

ʃi θɹu bæk əɹ kloʊk ən pʊɾ əɹ hænz ɑn ðə kɑləm, bʌt ɹænd sɔ hɝ wɑtʃɪŋ ɪm fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɝ aɪ. hi wɑz əwɛɹ ə nɝvəs kɑfɪŋ ən θɹoʊt-klɪɹɪŋ fɹəm ðə mɛn ɝaʊn ðə stoʊn, ə kɝs fɹəm ənoʊ ət sʌmwʌn hæŋɪŋ bæk, ə wik dʒoʊk fɹəm mæt, ə laʊd ɡʌlp fɹəm lɔɪəl. hi tʊk ðə vɔɪd.

She threw back her cloak and put her hands on the column, but Rand saw her watching him from the corner of her eye. He was aware of nervous coughing and throat-clearing from the men around the Stone, a curse from Uno at someone hanging back, a weak joke from Mat, a loud gulp from Loial. He took the void.

ɪt wɑz soʊ izi, naʊ. ðə fleɪm kənsum fɪɹ ən pæʃən ən wɑz ɡɔn ɔlmoʊs bɪfɔɹ i θɔt tə fɔɹm ɪt. ɡɔn, livɪŋ oʊnli ɛmptinəs, ən ʃaɪnɪŋ seɪɾɪn, sɪkənɪŋ, tæntəlaɪzɪŋ, stʌmək-tɝnɪŋ, sɪdʌktɪv. hi . . . ɹitʃt fəɹ ɪt . . . ən ɪt fɪl hɪm, meɪɾ ɪm əlaɪv. hi dɪd nɑt muv ə mʌsəl, bʌɾ i fɛlt əz ɪf i wɝ kwɪvɝɪŋ wɪð ðə ɹʌʃ ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ ɪndə hɪm. ðə sɪmbəl fɔɹmd ɪtsɛlf, ən æɹoʊ pɪɹsɪŋ ə sɝkəl, floʊɾɪŋ dʒʌs bɪɑn ðə vɔɪd, əz hɑɹɾ əz ðə stʌf ɪt wɑz kɑɹvd ɑn. hi lɛt ðə wʌn paʊɝ floʊ θɹu hɪm tə ðə sɪmbəl.

It was so easy, now. The flame consumed fear and passion and was gone almost before he thought to form it. Gone, leaving only emptiness, and shining saidin, sickening, tantalizing, stomach-turning, seductive. He . . . reached for it . . . and it filled him, made him alive. He did not move a muscle, but he felt as if he were quivering with the rush of the One Power into him. The symbol formed itself, an arrow piercing a circle, floating just beyond the void, as hard as the stuff it was carved on. He let the One Power flow through him to the symbol.

ðə sɪmbəl ʃɪmɝd, flɪkɝd.

The symbol shimmered, flickered.

"sʌmθɪŋ ɪz hæpənɪŋ," vɛɹɪn sɛd. "sʌmθɪŋ . . ."

"Something is happening," Verin said. "Something . . ."

ðə wɝl flɪkɝd.

The world flickered.

ði aɪɝn lɑk spʌn əkɹɔs ðə fɑɹmhaʊs flɔɹ, ən ɹænd dʒɹɑp ðə hɑt tikɛɾəl əz ə hjudʒ fɪɡjɝ wɪð ɹæmz hɔɹnz ɑn ɪts hɛd lumd ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ wɪð ðə dɑɹknəs ʌv wɪntɝnaɪt bɪhaɪn ɪt.

The iron lock spun across the farmhouse floor, and Rand dropped the hot teakettle as a huge figure with ram's horns on its head loomed in the doorway with the darkness of Winternight behind it.

"ɹʌn!" tæm ʃaʊɾəd. hɪz sɔɹd flæʃt, ən ðə tʃɹɑlɑk tɑpəld, bʌɾ ɪt ɡɹæpəld wɪð tæm əz ɪt fɛl, pʊlɪŋ ɪm daʊn.

"Run!" Tam shouted. His sword flashed, and the Trolloc toppled, but it grappled with Tam as it fell, pulling him down.

mɔɹ kɹaʊɾəd ɪn ət ðə dɔɹ, blæk-meɪld ʃeɪps wɪð hjumən feɪsəz dɪstɔɹɾəd wɪð mʌzəlz ən biks ən hɔɹnz, ɑdli kɝv sɔɹdz stæbɪŋ ət tæm əz i tʃɹaɪd tə stʃɹʌɡəl tə hɪz fit, spaɪkt æksiz swɪŋɪŋ, ɹɛd blʌɾ ɑn stil.

More crowded in at the door, black-mailed shapes with human faces distorted with muzzles and beaks and horns, oddly curved swords stabbing at Tam as he tried to struggle to his feet, spiked axes swinging, red blood on steel.

"fɑðɝ!" ɹænd skɹimd. klɔɪŋ ɪz bɛl naɪf fɹəm ɪts ʃiθ, hi θɹu hɪmsɛlf oʊvɝ ðə teɪbəl tə hɛlp ɪz fɑðɝ, ən skɹimd əɡɛn əz ðə fɝst sɔɹd ɹæn θɹu hɪz tʃɛst.

"Father!" Rand screamed. Clawing his belt knife from its sheath, he threw himself over the table to help his father, and screamed again as the first sword ran through his chest.

blʌd bʌbəld ʌp ɪndə hɪz maʊθ, ən ə vɔɪs wɪspɝɾ ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz hɛd, aɪ hæv wʌn əɡɛn, luz θɝɪn.

Blood bubbled up into his mouth, and a voice whispered inside his head, I have won again, Lews Therin.

flɪkɝ.

Flicker.

ɹænd stʃɹʌɡəl tə hoʊl ðə sɪmbəl, dɪmli əwɛɹ ə vɛɹɪnz vɔɪs. ". . . ɪz nɑt . . ."

Rand struggled to hold the symbol, dimly aware of Verin's voice. ". . . is not . . ."

ðə paʊɝ flʌɾəd.

The Power flooded.

flɪkɝ.

Flicker.

ɹænd wɑz hæpi æftɝ i mɛɹiɾ ɛɡwin, ən tʃɹaɪd tə nɑt lɛt ðə mudz teɪk hɪm, ðə taɪmz wən i θɔt ðəɹ ʃʊɾə bɪn sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ, sʌmθɪŋ dɪfɹənt. nuz ə ðə wɝld aʊtsaɪd keɪm ɪndə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz wɪð pɛdlɝz, ən mɝtʃəns kʌm tə baɪ wʊl ən təbæk, ɔlweɪz nuz ə fɹɛʃ tʃɹʌbəlz, ʌv wɔɹz ən fɔls dʒɹæɡənz ɛvɹiwɛɹ. ðəɹ wɑz ə jɪɹ wən niðɝ mɝtʃəns nɔɹ pɛdlɝz keɪm, ən wən ðeɪ ɹɪtɝn ðə nɛks ðeɪ bɹɔt wɝd ðəɾ ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz ɑɹmiz hæd kʌm bæk, əɹ ðɛɹ dɪsɛndəns, ət list. ði oʊl neɪʃənz wɝ bɹoʊkən, ɪt wɑz sɛd, ən ðə wɝlz nu mæstɝz, hu juz tʃeɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ðɛɹ bæɾəlz, hæd tɔɹn daʊn ðə waɪt taʊɝ ən sɔltəd ðə ɡɹaʊnd wɛɹ tɑɹ vəlɑn hæd stʊd. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ mɔɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Rand was happy after he married Egwene, and tried to not let the moods take him, the times when he thought there should have been something more, something different. News of the world outside came into the Two Rivers with peddlers, and merchants come to buy wool and tabac, always news of fresh troubles, of wars and false Dragons everywhere. There was a year when neither merchants nor peddlers came, and when they returned the next they brought word that Artur Hawkwing's armies had come back, or their descendants, at least. The old nations were broken, it was said, and the world's new masters, who used chained Aes Sedai in their battles, had torn down the White Tower and salted the ground where Tar Valon had stood. There were no more Aes Sedai.

ɪɾ ɔl meɪd lɪɾəl dɪfɝəns ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. kɹɑps stɪl hæd tə bi plæntəd, ʃip ʃɪɹd, læmz tɛndəd. tæm hæd ɡɹændsʌnz ən ɡɹændɔɾɝz tə dændəl ɑn ɪz ni bɪfɔɹ i wɑz leɪd tə ɹɛs bɪsaɪɾ ɪz waɪf, ən ði oʊl fɑɹmhaʊs ɡɹu nu ɹumz. ɛɡwin bɪkeɪm wɪzdəm, ən moʊs θɔt ʃi wɑz ivən bɛɾɝ ðən ði oʊld wɪzdəm, nɪneɪiv ælmɛɹə, hæd bɪn. ɪt wɑz əz wɛl ʃi wɑz, fəɹ əɹ kjʊɹz ðət wɝk soʊ mɝækjələsli ɑn ʌðɝz wɝ oʊnli dʒʌst eɪbəl tə kip ɹænd əlaɪv fɹəm ðə sɪknəs ðət kɑnstənli sim tə θɹɛɾən hɪm. hɪz mudz ɡɹu wɝs, blækɝ, ən i ɹeɪdʒ ðət ðɪs wɑz nɑt wʌt wɑz mɛn tə bi. ɛɡwin ɡɹu fɹaɪɾənd wən ðə mudz wɝ ɑn hɪm, fəɹ stʃɹeɪnʒ θɪŋz səmtaɪmz hæpənd wən i wɑz əɾ ɪz blikəst - laɪtnɪŋ stɔɹmz ʃi hæd nɑt hɝd lɪsnɪŋ tə ðə wɪnd, waɪldfaɪɝz ɪn ðə fɔɹəst - bʌt ʃi lʌvd ɪm ən kɛɹd fəɹ ɪm ən kɛpt ɪm seɪn, ðoʊ səm mʌɾɝd ðət ɹænd ælθɹ wɑz kɹeɪzi ən deɪnʒɝəs.

It all made little difference in the Two Rivers. Crops still had to be planted, sheep sheared, lambs tended. Tam had grandsons and granddaughters to dandle on his knee before he was laid to rest beside his wife, and the old farmhouse grew new rooms. Egwene became Wisdom, and most thought she was even better than the old Wisdom, Nynaeve al'Maera, had been. It was as well she was, for her cures that worked so miraculously on others were only just able to keep Rand alive from the sickness that constantly seemed to threaten him. His moods grew worse, blacker, and he raged that this was not what was meant to be. Egwene grew frightened when the moods were on him, for strange things sometimes happened when he was at his bleakest - lightning storms she had not heard listening to the wind, wildfires in the forest - but she loved him and cared for him and kept him sane, though some muttered that Rand al'Thor was crazy and dangerous.

wən ʃi daɪd, hi sæɾ əloʊn fəɹ lɔŋ aʊɝz baɪ hɝ ɡɹeɪv, tɪɹz soʊkɪŋ ɪz ɡɹeɪ-flɛk bɪɹd. hɪz sɪknəs keɪm bæk, ən i weɪstəd; hi lɔs ðə læs tu fɪŋɡɝz ɑn ɪz ɹaɪt hæn ən wʌn ɑn ɪz lɛft, hɪz ɪɹz lʊk laɪk skɑɹz, ən mɛn mʌɾɝd ðəɾ i smɛld ə dəkeɪ. hɪz blæknəs dipənd.

When she died, he sat alone for long hours by her grave, tears soaking his gray-flecked beard. His sickness came back, and he wasted; he lost the last two fingers on his right hand and one on his left, his ears looked like scars, and men muttered that he smelled of decay. His blackness deepened.

jɛt wən ðə daɪɹ nuz keɪm, nʌn ɹəfjuz tə æksɛpt ɪm ət ðɛɹ saɪd. tʃɹɑləks ən feɪdz ən θɪŋz əndʒɹimd ə hæd bɝst aʊɾ ə ðə blaɪt, ən ðə wɝlz nu mæstɝz wɝ biɪŋ θɹoʊn bæk, fəɹ ɔl ðə paʊɝz ðeɪ wildɪd. soʊ ɹænd tʊk ʌp ðə baʊ hi hæd dʒʌs fɪŋɡɝz ɪnʌf lɛf tə ʃuɾ ən lɪmpt wɪð ðoʊz u mɑɹtʃt nɔɹθ tə ðə ɹɪvɝ tɛɹən, mɛn fɹəm ɛvɹi vɪlədʒ, fɑɹm, ən kɔɹnɝ ə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, wɪð ðɛɹ baʊz, ən æksiz, ən bɔɹspɪɪɹz, ən sɔɹdz ðət hæd leɪn ɹʌstɪŋ ɪn æɾɪks. ɹænd wɔɹ ə sɔɹd, tu, wɪð ə hɛɹən ɑn ðə bleɪd, ðəɾ i hæd faʊn æftɝ tæm daɪd, ðoʊ hi nu nʌθɪŋ ə haʊ tə juz ɪt. wɪmən keɪm, tu, ʃoʊldɝɪŋ wʌt wɛpənz ðeɪ kəd faɪnd, mɑɹtʃɪŋ əlɔŋsaɪd ðə mɛn. səm læft, seɪɪŋ ðət ðeɪ hæd ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ filɪŋ ðeɪ hæd dʌn ðɪs bɪfɔɹ.

Yet when the dire news came, none refused to accept him at their side. Trollocs and Fades and things undreamed of had burst out of the Blight, and the world's new masters were being thrown back, for all the powers they wielded. So Rand took up the bow he had just fingers enough left to shoot and limped with those who marched north to the River Taren, men from every village, farm, and corner of the Two Rivers, with their bows, and axes, and boarspears, and swords that had lain rusting in attics. Rand wore a sword, too, with a heron on the blade, that he had found after Tam died, though he knew nothing of how to use it. Women came, too, shouldering what weapons they could find, marching alongside the men. Some laughed, saying that they had the strange feeling they had done this before.

ən ət ðə tɛɹən ðə pipəl ə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛt ði ɪnveɪɾɝz, ɛnləs ɹæŋks ə tʃɹɑləks lɛd baɪ naɪtmɛɹ feɪdz bɪniθ ə dɛd blæk bænɝ ðət sim tə it ðə laɪt. ɹænd sɔ ðət bænɝ ən θɔt ðə mædnəs hæd teɪkən ɪm əɡɛn, fəɹ ɪt sim ðət ðɪs wɑz wʌɾ i hæd bɪn bɔɹn fɔɹ, tə faɪt ðət bænɝ. hi sɛn ɛvɹi æɹoʊ əɾ ɪt, stʃɹeɪɾ əz ɪz skɪl ən ðə vɔɪd wəd sɝv, nɛvɝ wɝiɪŋ əbaʊt ðə tʃɹɑləks fɔɹsɪŋ ðɛɹ weɪ əkɹɔs ðə ɹɪvɝ, əɹ ðə mɛn ən wɪmən daɪɪŋ tə iðɝ saɪɾ ə hɪm. ɪt wɑz wʌn ə ðoʊz tʃɹɑləks ðət ɹæn ɪm θɹu, bɪfɔɹ ɪt loʊp haʊlɪŋ fəɹ blʌd dipɝ ɪndə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. ən əz i leɪ ɑn ðə bæŋk ə ðə tɛɹən, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə skaɪ sim tə ɡɹoʊ dɑɹk ət nun, bɹɛθ kʌmɪŋ ɛvɝ sloʊɝ, hi hɝɾ ə vɔɪs seɪ, aɪ hæv wʌn əɡɛn, luz θɝɪn.

And at the Taren the people of the Two Rivers met the invaders, endless ranks of Trollocs led by nightmare Fades beneath a dead black banner that seemed to eat the light. Rand saw that banner and thought the madness had taken him again, for it seemed that this was what he had been born for, to fight that banner. He sent every arrow at it, straight as his skill and the void would serve, never worrying about the Trollocs forcing their way across the river, or the men and women dying to either side of him. It was one of those Trollocs that ran him through, before it loped howling for blood deeper into the Two Rivers. And as he lay on the bank of the Taren, watching the sky seem to grow dark at noon, breath coming ever slower, he heard a voice say, I have won again, Lews Therin.

ði æɹoʊ-ænd-sɝkəl kəntɔɹɾəd ɪndə pɛɹəlɛl weɪvi laɪnz, ən i fɔɾ ɪt bæk əɡɛn.

The arrow-and-circle contorted into parallel wavy lines, and he fought it back again.
