tæm tʃɹaɪd tə kənsoʊl ɹænd wən ɛɡwin tʊk sɪk ən daɪd dʒʌst ə wik bɪfɔɹ ðɛɹ wɛɾɪŋ. nɪneɪiv tʃɹaɪd, tu, bʌt ʃi wɑz ʃeɪkən hɝsɛlf, sɪns fəɹ ɔl əɹ skɪl ʃi hæd noʊ aɪdiə wʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðət hæd kɪl ðə ɡɝl. ɹænd hæd sæɾ aʊtsaɪɾ ɛɡwinz haʊs waɪl ʃi daɪd, ən ðəɹ sim tə bi noʊwɛɹ ɪn ɛmənz fild i kəd ɡoʊ ðəɾ i dɪd nɑt stɪl hɪɹ əɹ skɹimɪŋ. hi nu hi kəd nɑt steɪ. tæm ɡeɪv ɪm ə sɔɹd wɪð ə hɛɹən-mɑɹk bleɪd, ən ðoʊ hi ɪkspleɪn lɪɾəl ə haʊ ə ʃɛpɝɾ ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz hæd kʌm baɪ sətʃ ə θɪŋ, hi tɔt ɹænd haʊ tə juz ɪt. ɑn ðə deɪ ɹænd lɛft, tæm ɡeɪv ɪm ə lɛɾɝ i sɛd maɪt ɡɛt ɹænd teɪkən ɪndə ði ɑɹmi ʌv ɪljən, ən hʌɡd hɪm, ən sɛd, "aɪv nɛvɝ hæɾ ənʌðɝ sʌn, əɹ wɑntəɾ ənʌðɝ. kʌm bæk wɪð ə waɪf laɪk aɪ dɪd, ɪf jə kæn, bɔɪ, bʌt kʌm bæk ɪn ɛni keɪs."

Tam tried to console Rand when Egwene took sick and died just a week before their wedding. Nynaeve tried, too, but she was shaken herself, since for all her skill she had no idea what it was that had killed the girl. Rand had sat outside Egwene's house while she died, and there seemed to be nowhere in Emond's Field he could go that he did not still hear her screaming. He knew he could not stay. Tam gave him a sword with a heron-mark blade, and though he explained little of how a shepherd in the Two Rivers had come by such a thing, he taught Rand how to use it. On the day Rand left, Tam gave him a letter he said might get Rand taken into the army of Illian, and hugged him, and said, "I've never had another son, or wanted another. Come back with a wife like I did, if you can, boy, but come back in any case."

ɹænd hæɾ ɪz mʌni stoʊlən ɪn bɛɹlən, ðoʊ, ən ɪz lɛɾɝ ʌv ɪntʃɹədʌkʃən, ən ɔlmoʊst ɪz sɔɹd, ən i mɛɾ ə wʊmən kɔl mɪn u toʊld ɪm sətʃ kɹeɪzi θɪŋz əbaʊt hɪmsɛlf ðəɾ i faɪnəli lɛf ðə sɪɾi tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ fɹəm hɝ. ɪvɛntʃəwəli hɪz wɑndɝɪŋz bɹɔɾ ɪm tə keɪɛmlɪn, ən ðəɹ ɪz skɪl wɪð ðə sɔɹɾ ɝn ɪm ə pleɪs ɪn ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz. səmtaɪmz i faʊn hɪmsɛlf lʊkɪŋ ət ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ, ɪleɪn, ən ət sətʃ taɪmz i wɑz fɪld wɪð ɑd θɔts ðət ðɪs wɑz nɑt ðə weɪ θɪŋz wɝ səpoʊz tə bi, ðət ðəɹ ʃəd bi sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ tə hɪz laɪf. ɪleɪn dɪd nɑt lʊk ət hɪm, ʌv kɔɹs; ʃi mɛɹiɾ ə tɛɹən pɹɪns, ðoʊ ʃi dɪd nɑt sim hæpi ɪn ɪt. ɹænd wɑz dʒʌst ə soʊlʒɝ, wʌns ə ʃɛpɝd fɹəm ə smɔl vɪlədʒ soʊ fɑɹ təwɔɹd ðə wɛstɝn bɔɹɾɝ ðəɾ oʊnli laɪnz ɑn ə mæp ɛni lɔŋɡɝ tʃɹuli kənɛktəɾ ɪt tə ændɝ. bɪsaɪdz, hi hæɾ ə dɑɹk ɹɛpjəteɪʃən, əz ə mæn ə vaɪələn mudz.

Rand had his money stolen in Baerlon, though, and his letter of introduction, and almost his sword, and he met a woman called Min who told him such crazy things about himself that he finally left the city to get away from her. Eventually his wanderings brought him to Caemlyn, and there his skill with the sword earned him a place in the Queen's Guards. Sometimes he found himself looking at the Daughter-Heir, Elayne, and at such times he was filled with odd thoughts that this was not the way things were supposed to be, that there should be something more to his life. Elayne did not look at him, of course; she married a Tairen prince, though she did not seem happy in it. Rand was just a soldier, once a shepherd from a small village so far toward the western border that only lines on a map any longer truly connected it to Andor. Besides, he had a dark reputation, as a man of violent moods.

səm sɛɾ i wɑz mæd, ən ɪn ɔɹɾənɛɹi taɪmz pɝhæps nɑɾ ivən ɪz skɪl wɪð ðə sɔɹd wʊɾə kɛpt ɪm ɪn ðə ɡɑɹd, bʌt ðiz wɝ nɑɾ ɔɹɾənɛɹi taɪmz. fɔls dʒɹæɡənz spɹæŋ ʌp laɪk widz. ɛvɹi taɪm wʌn wɑz teɪkən daʊn, tu mɔɹ pɹoʊkleɪm ðɛmsɛlvz, əɹ θɹi, tɪl ɛvɹi neɪʃən wɑz tɔɹn baɪ wɔɹ. ən ɹændz stɑɹ ɹoʊz, fəɹ i hæd lɝn ðə sikɹəɾ ə hɪz mædnəs, ə sikɹəɾ i nu hi hæd tə kip ən dɪd. hi kəd tʃænəl. ðəɹ wɝ ɔlweɪz pleɪsəz, taɪmz, ɪn ə bæɾəl wən ə lɪɾəl tʃænəlɪŋ, nɑt bɪɡ ɪnʌf tə bi noʊɾəst ɪn ðə kənfjuʒən, kəd meɪk lʌk. səmtaɪmz ɪt wɝkt, ðɪs tʃænəlɪŋ, ən səmtaɪmz nɑt, bʌɾ ɪt wɝkt ɔfən ɪnʌf. hi nu hi wɑz mæd, ən dɪd nɑt kɛɹ. ə weɪstɪŋ sɪknəs keɪm ɑn hɪm, ən i dɪd nɑt kɛɹ əbaʊt ðæt, iðɝ, ən niðɝ dɪɾ ɛniwʌn ɛls, fəɹ wɝd hæd kʌm ðəɾ ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz ɑɹmiz hæd ɹɪtɝn tə ɹikleɪm ðə lænd.

Some said he was mad, and in ordinary times perhaps not even his skill with the sword would have kept him in the Guard, but these were not ordinary times. False Dragons sprang up like weeds. Every time one was taken down, two more proclaimed themselves, or three, till every nation was torn by war. And Rand's star rose, for he had learned the secret of his madness, a secret he knew he had to keep and did. He could channel. There were always places, times, in a battle when a little channeling, not big enough to be noticed in the confusion, could make luck. Sometimes it worked, this channeling, and sometimes not, but it worked often enough. He knew he was mad, and did not care. A wasting sickness came on him, and he did not care about that, either, and neither did anyone else, for word had come that Artur Hawkwing's armies had returned to reclaim the land.

ɹænd lɛɾ ə θaʊzən mɛn wən ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz kɹɔs ðə maʊntənz ə mɪst - hi nɛvɝ θɔɾ ə tɝnɪŋ əsaɪd tə vɪzət ðə tu ɹɪvɝz; hi sɛldəm θɔɾ ə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz əɾ ɔl, ɛnimɔɹ - ən i kəmændəd ðə ɡɑɹd wən ðə ʃæɾɝd ɹɛmnəns ɹitʃɹiɾəd bæk əkɹɔs ðə maʊntənz. ðə lɛŋθ ʌv ændɝ i fɔɾ ən fɛl bæk, əmɪd hɔɹdz ə fliɪŋ ɹɛfjudʒiz, əntɪl ət læst i keɪm tə keɪɛmlɪn. mɛni ʌv ðə pipəl ə keɪɛmlɪn hæd flɛɾ ɔlɹɛɾi, ən mɛni kaʊnsəl ði ɑɹmi tə ɹitʃɹit fɝðɝ, bʌɾ ɪleɪn wɑz kwin, naʊ, ən vaʊd ʃi wəd nɑt liv keɪɛmlɪn. ʃi wəd nɑt lʊk əɾ ɪz ɹuən feɪs, skɑɹd baɪ hɪz sɪknəs, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt liv hɝ, ən soʊ wʌt wɑz lɛft ə ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz pɹipɛɹd tə dɪfɛn ðə kwin waɪl əɹ pipəl ɹæn.

Rand led a thousand men when the Queen's Guards crossed the Mountains of Mist - he never thought of turning aside to visit the Two Rivers; he seldom thought of the Two Rivers at all, anymore - and he commanded the Guard when the shattered remnants retreated back across the mountains. The length of Andor he fought and fell back, amid hordes of fleeing refugees, until at last he came to Caemlyn. Many of the people of Caemlyn had fled already, and many counseled the army to retreat further, but Elayne was Queen, now, and vowed she would not leave Caemlyn. She would not look at his ruined face, scarred by his sickness, but he could not leave her, and so what was left of the Queen's Guards prepared to defend the Queen while her people ran.

ðə paʊɝ keɪm tə hɪm dʊɹɪŋ ðə bæɾəl fəɹ keɪɛmlɪn, ən i hɝld laɪtnɪŋ ən faɪɝ əmʌŋ ði ɪnveɪɾɝz, ən splɪt ði ɝθ ʌndɝ ðɛɹ fit, jɛt ðə filɪŋ keɪm əɡɛn, tu, ðəɾ i hæd bɪn bɔɹn fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ ɛls. fəɹ ɔl i dɪd, ðəɹ wɝ tu mɛni ʌv ði ɛnəmi tə stɑp, ən ðeɪ ɔlsoʊ hæd ðoʊz u kəd tʃænəl. ət læst, ə laɪtnɪŋ boʊl hɝld ɹænd fɹəm ðə pæləs wɔl, bɹoʊkən, bliɾɪŋ, ən bɝnd, ən əz ɪz læs bɹɛθ ɹæɾəld ɪn ɪz θɹoʊt, hi hɝɾ ə vɔɪs wɪspɝ, aɪ hæv wʌn əɡɛn, luz θɝɪn.

The Power came to him during the battle for Caemlyn, and he hurled lightning and fire among the invaders, and split the earth under their feet, yet the feeling came again, too, that he had been born for something else. For all he did, there were too many of the enemy to stop, and they also had those who could channel. At last, a lightning bolt hurled Rand from the Palace wall, broken, bleeding, and burned, and as his last breath rattled in his throat, he heard a voice whisper, I have won again, Lews Therin.

Rand struggled to hold the void as it quivered under the hammer blows of the world flickering, to hold the one symbol as a thousand of them darted along the surface of the void. He struggled to hold on to any one symbol.

He was a soldier. He was a shepherd. He was a beggar, and a king. He was farmer, gleeman, sailor, carpenter. He was born, lived, and died an Aiel. He died mad, he died rotting, he died of sickness, accident, age. He was executed, and multitudes cheered his death. He proclaimed himself the Dragon Reborn and flung his banner across the sky; he ran from the Power and hid; he lived and died never knowing. He held off the madness and the sickness for years; he succumbed between two winters. Sometimes Moiraine came and took him away from the Two Rivers, alone or with those of his friends who had survived Winternight; sometimes she did not. Sometimes other Aes Sedai came for him. Sometimes the Red Ajah. Egwene married him; Egwene, stern-faced in the stole of the Amyrlin Seat, led the Aes Sedai who gentled him; Egwene, with tears in her eyes, plunged a dagger into his heart, and he thanked her as he died. He loved other women, married other women. Elayne, and Min, and a fair-haired farmer's daughter met on the road to Caemlyn, and women he had never seen before he lived those lives. A hundred lives. More. So many he could not count them. And at the end of every life, as he lay dying, as he drew his final breath, a voice whispered in his ear. I have won again, Lews Therin. ðə vɔɪd vænɪʃt, kɑntækt wɪð seɪɾɪn flɛd, ən ɹænd fɛl wɪð ə θʌd ðət wʊɾə nɑk ðə bɹɛθ aʊɾ ə hɪm ɪf i hæd nɑɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bɪn hæf nʌm. hi fɛlt ɹʌf stoʊn ʌndɝ ɪz tʃik, ən ɪz hænz. ɪt wɑz koʊld.

The void vanished, contact with saidin fled, and Rand fell with a thud that would have knocked the breath out of him if he had not already been half numb. He felt rough stone under his cheek, and his hands. It was cold.

hi wɑz əwɛɹ ə vɛɹɪn, stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ fɹəm əɹ bæk tə hænz ən niz. hi hɝd sʌmwʌn vɑmət ɹʌfli, ən ɹeɪzd ɪz hɛd. ənoʊ wɑz nilɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, skɹʌbɪŋ ðə bæk ə hɪz hæn əkɹɔs ɪz maʊθ. ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz daʊn, ən ðə hɔɹsəz stʊd stɪf-lɛɡəɾ ən kwɪvɝɪŋ, aɪz waɪld ən ɹoʊlɪŋ. ɪŋtʃɹ hæɾ ɪz sɔɹɾ aʊt, ɡɹɪpɪŋ ðə hɪl soʊ hɑɹd ðə bleɪd ʃʊk, stɛɹɪŋ ət nʌθɪŋ. lɔɪəl sæt spɹɔld, waɪd-aɪɾ ən stʌnd. mæt wɑz hʌɾəld ɪn ə bɔl wɪð ɪz ɑɹmz ɹæpt ɝaʊn ɪz hɛd, ən pɛɹɪn hæɾ ɪz fɪŋɡɝz dʌɡ ɪndə hɪz feɪs əz ɪf i wɑntəd tə ɹɪp əweɪ wʌtɛvɝ i hæd sin, əɹ pɝhæps ɹɪp aʊt ði aɪz ðət hæd sin ɪt. nʌn ə ðə soʊlʒɝz wɝ ɛni bɛɾɝ. mæsimə wɛpt oʊpənli, tɪɹz stʃɹimɪŋ daʊn ɪz feɪs, ən hʊɹɪn wɑz lʊkɪŋ ɝaʊn əz ɪf fəɹ ə pleɪs tə ɹʌn.

He was aware of Verin, struggling from her back to hands and knees. He heard someone vomit roughly, and raised his head. Uno was kneeling on the ground, scrubbing the back of his hand across his mouth. Everyone was down, and the horses stood stiff-legged and quivering, eyes wild and rolling. Ingtar had his sword out, gripping the hilt so hard the blade shook, staring at nothing. Loial sat sprawled, wide-eyed and stunned. Mat was huddled in a ball with his arms wrapped around his head, and Perrin had his fingers dug into his face as if he wanted to rip away whatever he had seen, or perhaps rip out the eyes that had seen it. None of the soldiers were any better. Masema wept openly, tears streaming down his face, and Hurin was looking around as if for a place to run.

"wʌt . . . ?" ɹænd stɑp tə swɑloʊ. hi wɑz laɪɪŋ ɑn ɹʌf, wɛðɝd stoʊn hæf bɛɹiɾ ɪn ðə dɝt. "wʌt hæpənd?"

"What . . . ?" Rand stopped to swallow. He was lying on rough, weathered stone half buried in the dirt. "What happened?"

"ə sɝdʒ ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ." ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tɑɾɝd tə hɝ fiɾ ən pʊld əɹ kloʊk taɪt wɪð ə ʃɪvɝ. "ɪt wɑz əz ɪf wi wɝ biɪŋ fɔɹst . . . pʊʃt. . . . ɪt sim tə kʌm aʊɾ ə noʊwɛɹ. jə mʌs lɝn tə kəntʃɹoʊl ɪt. jə mʌst! ðət mʌtʃ ə ðə paʊɝ kəd bɝn jə tə ə sɪndɝ."

"A surge of the One Power." The Aes Sedai tottered to her feet and pulled her cloak tight with a shiver. "It was as if we were being forced . . . pushed. . . . It seemed to come out of nowhere. You must learn to control it. You must! That much of the Power could burn you to a cinder."

"vɛɹɪn, aɪ. . . . aɪ lɪvd. . . . aɪ wɑz. . . ." hi ɹilaɪz ðə stoʊn ʌndɝ ɪm wɑz ɹaʊndəd. ðə pɔɹɾəl stoʊn. heɪstəli, ʃɑkəli, hi pʊʃt hɪmsɛlf tə hɪz fit. "vɛɹɪn, aɪ lɪvd ən daɪd, aɪ doʊnt noʊ haʊ mɛni taɪmz. ɛvɹi taɪm ɪt wɑz dɪfɹənt, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz mi. ɪt wɑz mi."

"Verin, I. . . . I lived. . . . I was. . . ." He realized the stone under him was rounded. The Portal Stone. Hastily, shakily, he pushed himself to his feet. "Verin, I lived and died, I don't know how many times. Every time it was different, but it was me. It was me."

"ðə laɪnz ðət dʒɔɪn ðə wɝlz ðət maɪt bi, leɪd baɪ ðoʊz u nu ðə nʌmbɝz ə keɪɑs." vɛɹɪn ʃʌɾɝəd; ʃi sim tə bi tɔkɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf. "aɪv nɛvɝ hɝɾ ɪt, bʌt ðəɹ ɪz noʊ ɹizən wi wəd nɑt bi bɔɹn ɪn ðoʊz wɝlz, jɛt ðə laɪvz wi lɪvd wəd bi dɪfɹən laɪvz. ʌv kɔɹs. dɪfɹən lɪvz fəɹ ðə dɪfɹənt weɪz θɪŋz maɪɾ əv hæpənd."

"The Lines that join the Worlds That Might Be, laid by those who knew the Numbers of Chaos." Verin shuddered; she seemed to be talking to herself. "I've never heard it, but there is no reason we would not be born in those worlds, yet the lives we lived would be different lives. Of course. Different lives for the different ways things might have happened."

"ɪz ðət wʌt hæpənd? aɪ . . . wi . . . sɔ haʊ əɹ laɪvz kəɾ əv bɪn?" aɪ hæv wʌn əɡɛn, luz θɝɪn. noʊ! aɪm ɹænd ælθɹ!

"Is that what happened? I . . . we . . . saw how our lives could have been?" I have won again, Lews Therin. No! I am Rand al'Thor!

vɛɹɪn ɡeɪv hɝsɛlf ə ʃeɪk ən lʊkt ət hɪm. "dʌz ɪt sɝpɹaɪz jə ðət jəɹ laɪf maɪt ɡoʊ dɪfɹənli ɪf jə meɪd dɪfɹən tʃɔɪsəz, əɹ dɪfɹən θɪŋz hæpən tə ju? ðoʊ aɪ nɛvɝ θɔɾ aɪ - wɛl. ði ɪmpɔɹɾənt θɪŋ ɪz, wəɹ hɪɹ. ðoʊ nɑɾ əz wi hoʊpt."

Verin gave herself a shake and looked at him. "Does it surprise you that your life might go differently if you made different choices, or different things happened to you? Though I never thought I - Well. The important thing is, we are here. Though not as we hoped."

"wɛɹ ɪz hɪɹ?" hi dɪmændəd. ðə wʊdz ə stɛɾɪŋ tsəfu wɝ ɡɔn, ɹipleɪs baɪ ɹoʊlɪŋ lænd. ðəɹ sim tə bi fɔɹəs nɑt fɑɹ tə ðə wɛst, ən ə fju hɪlz. ɪt hæd bɪn haɪ ɪn ðə deɪ wən ðeɪ ɡæðɝɾ ɝaʊn ðə stoʊn ɪn ðə stɛɾɪŋ bʌt hɪɹ ðə sʌn stʊd loʊ təwɔɹɾ æftɝnun ɪn ə ɡɹeɪ skaɪ. ðə hændfʊl ə tʃɹiz nɪɹbaɪ wɝ bɛɹ bɹæntʃt, əɹ ɛls hɛld ə fju livz bɹaɪt wɪð kʌlɝ. ə koʊld wɪnd ɡʌstɪd fɹəm ði ist, sɛndɪŋ livz skɝiɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə ɡɹaʊnd.

"Where is here?" he demanded. The woods of Stedding Tsofu were gone, replaced by rolling land. There seemed to be forest not far to the west, and a few hills. It had been high in the day when they gathered around the Stone in the stedding but here the sun stood low toward afternoon in a gray sky. The handful of trees nearby were bare branched, or else held a few leaves bright with color. A cold wind gusted from the east, sending leaves scurrying across the ground.

"toʊmən hɛd," vɛɹɪn sɛd. "ðɪs ɪz ðə stoʊn aɪ vɪzəɾəd. jə ʃəd nɑɾ əv tʃɹaɪd tə bɹɪŋ əs dɝɛkli hɪɹ. aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt wɛn ɹɔŋ - aɪ doʊn səpoʊz aɪ ɛvɝ wɪl - bʌt fɹəm ðə tʃɹiz, aɪ wəd seɪ ɪts wɛl ɪndə leɪɾ ɔɾəm. ɹænd, wi hævənt ɡeɪn ɛni taɪm baɪ ɪt. wiv lɔs taɪm. aɪ wəd seɪ wɪv izəli spɛn fɔɹ mʌnθs ɪn kʌmɪŋ hɪɹ."

"Toman Head," Verin said. "This is the Stone I visited. You should not have tried to bring us directly here. I don't know what went wrong - I don't suppose I ever will - but from the trees, I would say it is well into late autumn. Rand, we haven't gained any time by it. We've lost time. I would say we have easily spent four months in coming here."

"bʌɾ aɪ dɪdnt - "

"But I didn't - "

"ju mʌs lemi ɡaɪd jə ɪn ðiz θɪŋz. aɪ kænɑt titʃ ju, ɪts tʃɹu, bʌt pɝhæps aɪ kən ət lis kip jə fɹəm kɪlɪŋ jɝsɛlf - ən ðə ɹɛst ʌv əs - baɪ oʊvɝɹitʃɪŋ. ivən ɪf jə də nɑt kɪl jɝsɛlf, ɪf ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn bɝnz hɪmsɛlf aʊt laɪk ə ɡʌɾɝɪŋ kændəl, hu wɪl feɪs ðə dɑɹk wʌn ðɛn?" ʃi dɪd nɑt weɪt fəɹ ɪm tə ɹɪnu hɪz pɹoʊɾɛsts, bʌt wɛn tə ɪŋtʃɹ ɪnstɛd.

"You must let me guide you in these things. I cannot teach you, it's true, but perhaps I can at least keep you from killing yourself - and the rest of us - by overreaching. Even if you do not kill yourself, if the Dragon Reborn burns himself out like a guttering candle, who will face the Dark One then?" She did not wait for him to renew his protests, but went to Ingtar instead.

ðə ʃaɪnɝən ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt wən ʃi tʌtʃt ɪz ɑɹm, ən lʊkt əɾ əɹ wɪð fɹæntɪk aɪz. "aɪ wɔk ɪn ðə laɪt," hi sɛd hɔɹsli. "aɪ wɪl faɪn ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ ən pʊl daʊn ʃeɪɑl ɡʌlz paʊɝ. aɪ wɪl!"

The Shienaran gave a start when she touched his arm, and looked at her with frantic eyes. "I walk in the Light," he said hoarsely. "I will find the Horn of Valere and pull down Shayol Ghul's power. I will!"

"ʌv kɔɹs jə wɪl," ʃi sɛd suðɪŋli. ʃi tʊk ɪz feɪs ɪn əɹ hænz, ən i dʒɹu ə sʌɾən bɹɛθ, əbɹʌpli ɹəkʌvɝɪŋ fɹəm wʌtɛvɝ hæd hɛl hɪm. ɪksɛp ðət mɛmɹi stɪl leɪ ɪn ɪz aɪz. "ðɛɹ," ʃi sɛd. "ðæt wɪl də fəɹ ju. əl si haʊ aɪ kən hɛlp ðə ɹɛst. wi meɪ stɪl ɹɪkʌvɝ ðə hɔɹn, bʌɾ əɹ pæθ əz nɑt ɡɹoʊn smuðɝ."

"Of course you will," she said soothingly. She took his face in her hands, and he drew a sudden breath, abruptly recovering from whatever had held him. Except that memory still lay in his eyes. "There," she said. "That will do for you. I will see how I can help the rest. We may still recover the Horn, but our path has not grown smoother."

əz ʃi stɑɹɾəd ɝaʊn əmʌŋ ði ʌðɝz, stɑpɪŋ bɹifli baɪ itʃ, ɹænd wɛn tə hɪz fɹɛnz. wən i tʃɹaɪd tə stʃɹeɪɾən mæt, mæt dʒɝkt ən stɛɹɾ ət hɪm, ðən ɡɹæbd ɹændz koʊt wɪð boʊθ hænz. "ɹænd, aɪd nɛvɝ tɛl ɛniwʌn əbaʊt - əbaʊt ju. aɪ wʊdn bɪtʃɹeɪ ju. juv tə bɪliv ðæt!" hi lʊkt wɝs ðən ɛvɝ, bʌt ɹænd θɔɾ ɪt wɑz moʊsli fɹaɪt.

As she started around among the others, stopping briefly by each, Rand went to his friends. When he tried to straighten Mat, Mat jerked and stared at him, then grabbed Rand's coat with both hands. "Rand, I'd never tell anyone about - about you. I wouldn't betray you. You have to believe that!" He looked worse than ever, but Rand thought it was mostly fright.

"aɪ du," ɹænd sɛd. hi wʌndɝd wʌt lɪvz mæt hæd lɪvd, ən wʌɾ i hæd dʌn. hi mʌst əv toʊl sʌmwʌn, əɹ i wʊdn bi soʊ æŋkʃəs əbaʊɾ ɪt. hi kəd nɑt hoʊld ɪɾ əɡɛns hɪm. ðoʊz hæd bɪn ʌðɝ mæts, nɑt ðɪs wʌn. bɪsaɪdz, æftɝ səm ə ði ɔltɝnəɾɪvz i hæd sin fəɹ hɪmsɛlf. . . . "aɪ bɪliv ju. pɛɹɪn?"

"I do," Rand said. He wondered what lives Mat had lived, and what he had done. He must have told someone, or he wouldn't be so anxious about it. He could not hold it against him. Those had been other Mats, not this one. Besides, after some of the alternatives he had seen for himself. . . . "I believe you. Perrin?"

ðə kɝli-hɛɹd juθ dʒɹɑpt ɪz hænz fɹəm ɪz feɪs wɪð ə saɪ. ɹɛd mɑɹks skɔɹɾ ɪz fɔɹhɛɾ ən tʃiks wɛɹ ɪz neɪlz hæd dʌɡ ɪn. hɪz jɛloʊ aɪz hɪɾ ɪz θɔts. "wi doʊn əv mɛni tʃɔɪsəz ɹɪli, də wi, ɹænd? wʌtɛvɝ hæpənz, wʌtɛvɝ wi du, səm θɪŋz ɑɹ ɔlmoʊst ɔlweɪz ðə seɪm." hi lɛɾ aʊɾ ənʌðɝ lɔŋ bɹɛθ. "wɛɹ ɑɹ wi? ɪz ðɪs wʌn ə ðoʊz wɝlz jə ən hʊɹɪn wɝ tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt?"

The curly-haired youth dropped his hands from his face with a sigh. Red marks scored his forehead and cheeks where his nails had dug in. His yellow eyes hid his thoughts. "We don't have many choices really, do we, Rand? Whatever happens, whatever we do, some things are almost always the same." He let out another long breath. "Where are we? Is this one of those worlds you and Hurin were talking about?"

"ɪts toʊmən hɛd," ɹænd toʊl hɪm. "ɪn əɹ wɝld. əɹ soʊ vɛɹɪn sɛz. ən ɪts ɔɾəm."

"It's Toman Head," Rand told him. "In our world. Or so Verin says. And it is autumn."

mæt lʊkt wɝid. "haʊ kəd - ? noʊ, aɪ doʊnt wɑnə noʊ haʊ ɪt hæpənd. bʌt haʊ ɑɹ wi gɑnə faɪn feɪn ən ðə dæɡɝ naʊ? hi kəd bi ɛniwɛɹ baɪ ðɪs taɪm."

Mat looked worried. "How could - ? No, I don't want to know how it happened. But how are we going to find Fain and the dagger now? He could be anywhere by this time."

"hiz hɪɹ," ɹænd əʃʊɹd hɪm. hi hoʊpt i wɑz ɹaɪt. feɪn hæd hæd taɪm tə teɪk ʃɪp fəɹ ɛnipleɪs i wɑntəd tə ɡoʊ. taɪm tə ɹaɪd tə ɛmənz fild. əɹ tɑɹ vəlɑn. pliz, laɪt, hi dɪdnt ɡɛt taɪɝɾ ʌv weɪɾɪŋ. ɪf hiz hɝɾ ɛɡwin, əɹ ɛnibəɾi ɪn ɛmənz fild, aɪl. . . . laɪt bɝn mi, aɪ tʃɹaɪd tə kʌm ɪn taɪm.

"He's here," Rand assured him. He hoped he was right. Fain had had time to take ship for anyplace he wanted to go. Time to ride to Emond's Field. Or Tar Valon. Please, Light, he didn't get tired of waiting. If he's hurt Egwene, or anybody in Emond's Field, I'll. . . . Light burn me, I tried to come in time.

"ðə lɑɹdʒɝ taʊnz ɑn toʊmən hɛɾ ɑɹ ɔl wɛst ə hɪɹ," vɛɹɪn ənaʊns laʊdli ɪnʌf fəɹ ɔl tə hɪɹ. ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz ɑn ðɛɹ fiɾ əɡɛn, ɪksɛp fəɹ ɹænd ən ɪz tu fɹɛnz; ʃi keɪm ən pʊɾ əɹ hænz ɑn mæt əz ʃi spoʊk. "nɑt ðət ðəɹ ɑɹ mɛni vɪlədʒəz lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf tə kɔl taʊnz. ɪf wəɹ tə faɪn ɛni tʃɹeɪs ə ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz, tə ðə wɛst ɪz ðə pleɪs tə bɪɡɪn. ən aɪ θɪŋk wi ʃəd nɑt weɪs ðə deɪlaɪt sɪɾɪŋ hɪɹ."

"The larger towns on Toman Head are all west of here," Verin announced loudly enough for all to hear. Everyone was on their feet again, except for Rand and his two friends; she came and put her hands on Mat as she spoke. "Not that there are many villages large enough to call towns. If we are to find any trace of the Darkfriends, to the west is the place to begin. And I think we should not waste the daylight sitting here."

wən mæt blɪŋkt ən stʊɾ ʌp - hi stɪl lʊkt ɪl, bʌɾ i muv spɹɪli - ʃi pʊɾ əɹ hænz ɑn pɛɹɪn. ɹænd bækt əweɪ wən ʃi ɹitʃt fəɹ hɪm.

When Mat blinked and stood up - he still looked ill, but he moved spryly - she put her hands on Perrin. Rand backed away when she reached for him.

"doʊn bi fulɪʃ," ʃi toʊl hɪm.

"Don't be foolish," she told him.

"aɪ doʊnt wɑn jəɹ hɛlp," hi sɛd kwaɪətli. "ɔɹ ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ hɛlp."

"I don't want your help," he said quietly. "Or any Aes Sedai help."

hɝ lɪps twɪtʃt. "æz jə wɪʃ."

Her lips twitched. "As you wish."

ðeɪ maʊntəɾ ɪmiɾiətli ən ɹoʊd wɛst, livɪŋ ðə pɔɹɾəl stoʊn bɪhaɪnd. noʊ wʌn pɹətɛstəd, ɹænd list ʌv ɔl. laɪt, lemi nɑt bi tu leɪt.

They mounted immediately and rode west, leaving the Portal Stone behind. No one protested, Rand least of all. Light, let me not be too late.


tʃæptɝ θɝɾieɪt

pɹæktəs


Practice

sɪɾɪŋ kɹɔs-lɛɡəɾ ɑn əɹ bɛɾ ɪn əɹ waɪt dʒɹɛs, ɛɡwin meɪd θɹi taɪni bɔlz ə laɪt wiv pæɾɝnz əbʌv əɹ hænz. ʃi wɑz nɑt səpoʊz tə də ðɪs wɪθaʊɾ ət list wʌn ə ði æksɛptɪd tə supɝvaɪz, bʌt nɪneɪiv, ɡlɛɹɪŋ ən stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ ʌp ən daʊn ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə smɔl faɪɝpleɪs, dɪɾ æftɝ ɔl wɛɹ ðə sɝpən ɹɪŋ ɡɪvən tə ði æksɛptɪd, ən əɹ waɪt dʒɹɛs hæd ðə kʌlɝd ɹɪŋz ɛnsɝkəlɪŋ ðə hɛm, ivən ɪf ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əlaʊd tə tʃɹaɪ tə titʃ ɛniwʌn jɛt. ən ɛɡwin hæd faʊn oʊvɝ ðiz læs θɝtin wiks ðət ʃi kəd nɑt ɹɪzɪst. ʃi nu haʊ izi ɪt wɑz tə tʌtʃ seɪaɪdɑɹ naʊ. ʃi kəɾ ɔlweɪz fil ɪt ðɛɹ, weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ hɝ, laɪk ðə smɛl ə pɝfjum əɹ ðə fil ə sɪlk, dʒɹɔɪŋ hɝ, dʒɹɔɪŋ hɝ. ən wʌns ʃi dɪd tʌtʃ ɪt, ʃi kəd ɹɛɹli stɑp fɹəm tʃænəlɪŋ, əɹ ət lis tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə. ʃi feɪld ɔlmoʊst əz ɔfən əz ʃi səksiɾəd, bʌt ðət wɑz oʊnli ənʌðɝ spɝ tə kip ɑn.

Sitting cross-legged on her bed in her white dress, Egwene made three tiny balls of light weave patterns above her hands. She was not supposed to do this without at least one of the Accepted to supervise, but Nynaeve, glaring and striding up and down in front of the small fireplace, did after all wear the Serpent ring given to the Accepted, and her white dress had the colored rings encircling the hem, even if she was not allowed to try to teach anyone yet. And Egwene had found over these last thirteen weeks that she could not resist. She knew how easy it was to touch saidar now. She could always feel it there, waiting for her, like the smell of perfume or the feel of silk, drawing her, drawing her. And once she did touch it, she could rarely stop from channeling, or at least trying to. She failed almost as often as she succeeded, but that was only another spur to keep on.

ɪɾ ɔfən fɹaɪɾənd hɝ. haʊ mʌtʃ ʃi wɑntəd tə tʃænəl fɹaɪɾənd hɝ, ən haʊ dʒɹæb ən dʒɹɪɹi ʃi fɛlt wən ʃi wɑz nɑt tʃænəlɪŋ, kəmpɛɹd tə wən ʃi wɑz. ʃi wɑntəd tə dʒɹɪŋk ɪɾ ɔl ɪn, dɪspaɪt ðə kɔʃənz əbaʊt bɝnɪŋ hɝsɛlf aʊt, ən ðət wɑntɪŋ fɹaɪɾənd əɹ moʊst ʌv ɔl. səmtaɪmz ʃi wɪʃt ʃi hæd nɛvɝ kʌm tə tɑɹ vəlɑn. bʌt ðə fɹaɪt kəd nɑt meɪk əɹ stɑp fəɹ lɔŋ, ɛni mɔɹ ðən ðə fɪɹ ə biɪŋ kɑt baɪ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ əɹ baɪ ɛni ʌv ði æksɛptɪd bɪsaɪd nɪneɪiv.

It often frightened her. How much she wanted to channel frightened her, and how drab and dreary she felt when she was not channeling, compared to when she was. She wanted to drink it all in, despite the cautions about burning herself out, and that wanting frightened her most of all. Sometimes she wished she had never come to Tar Valon. But the fright could not make her stop for long, any more than the fear of being caught by an Aes Sedai or by any of the Accepted beside Nynaeve.

ɪt wɑz seɪf ɪnʌf hɪɹ, ðoʊ, ɪn əɹ oʊn ɹum. mɪn wɑz ðɛɹ, sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə θɹi-lɛɡəd stul wɑtʃɪŋ hɝ, bʌt ʃi nu mɪn wɛl ɪnʌf naʊ tə noʊ mɪn wəd nɛvɝ ɹipɔɹt hɝ. ʃi θɔt ʃi wɑz lʌki tə hæv meɪd tu ɡʊd fɹɛnz sɪns kʌmɪŋ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn.

It was safe enough here, though, in her own room. Min was there, sitting on the three-legged stool watching her, but she knew Min well enough now to know Min would never report her. She thought she was lucky to have made two good friends since coming to Tar Valon.

ɪt wɑz ə lɪɾəl, wɪndoʊləs ɹum, əz ɔl nɑvəsɪz' ɹumz wɝ. θɹi ʃɔɹt peɪsɪz tʊk nɪneɪiv fɹəm wɔl tə waɪt-plæstɝd wɔl; nɪneɪivz oʊn ɹum wɑz mʌtʃ lɑɹdʒɝ, bʌt sɪns ʃi hæd meɪd noʊ fɹɛnz əmʌŋ ði ʌðɝ æksɛptɪd, ʃi keɪm tə ɛɡwinz ɹum wən ʃi niɾəd sʌmwʌn tə tɔk tə, ivən əz naʊ wən ʃi dɪd nɑt tɔk əɾ ɔl. ðə taɪni faɪɝ ɑn ðə nɛɹoʊ hɑɹθ hændəli kɛp ðə fɝs tʃɪl ʌv əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ ɔɾəm ət beɪ, ðoʊ ɛɡwin wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪt wəd nɑt sɝv soʊ wɛl wən wɪntɝ keɪm. ə smɔl teɪbəl fəɹ stʌɾi kəmpliɾəd ðə fɝnɪʃɪŋz, ən əɹ bɪlɔŋɪŋz hʌŋ nitli ɑn ə ɹoʊ ʌv pɛɡz ɑn ðə wɔl əɹ sæɾ ɑn ðə ʃɔɹt ʃɛlf əbʌv ðə teɪbəl. nɑvəsɪz wɝ juʒəwəli kɛp tu bɪzi tə spɛn taɪm ɪn ðɛɹ ɹumz, bʌt tədeɪ wɑz ə fɹideɪ, oʊnli ðə θɝd sɪns ʃi ən nɪneɪiv hæd kʌm tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ.

It was a little, windowless room, as all novices' rooms were. Three short paces took Nynaeve from wall to white-plastered wall; Nynaeve's own room was much larger, but since she had made no friends among the other Accepted, she came to Egwene's room when she needed someone to talk to, even as now when she did not talk at all. The tiny fire on the narrow hearth handily kept the first chill of approaching autumn at bay, though Egwene was sure it would not serve so well when winter came. A small table for study completed the furnishings, and her belongings hung neatly on a row of pegs on the wall or sat on the short shelf above the table. Novices were usually kept too busy to spend time in their rooms, but today was a freeday, only the third since she and Nynaeve had come to the White Tower.

"ɛls wɑz meɪkɪŋ kæfs aɪz ət ɡɑləd tədeɪ waɪl i wɑz wɝkɪŋ wɪð ðə wɔɹɾɝz," mɪn sɛd, ɹɑkɪŋ ðə stul ɑn tu lɛɡz.

"Else was making calf's eyes at Galad today while he was working with the Warders," Min said, rocking the stool on two legs.

ðə smɔl bɔlz fɔltɝd fəɹ ən ɪnstən əbʌv ɛɡwinz hænz. "ʃi kən lʊk ət huɛvɝ ʃi wɑns," ɛɡwin sɛd kæʒəwəli. "aɪ kæn ɪmædʒən waɪ aɪ wəd bi ɪntʃɹəstəd."

The small balls faltered for an instant above Egwene's hands. "She can look at whoever she wants," Egwene said casually. "I can't imagine why I would be interested."

"noʊ ɹizən, aɪ səpoʊz. hiz ɑfli hænsəm, ɪf jə doʊn maɪn ɪm biɪŋ soʊ ɹɪdʒəd. vɛɹi naɪs tə lʊk æt, ɪspɛʃli wɪð ɪz ʃɝɾ ɔf."

"No reason, I suppose. He is awfully handsome, if you don't mind him being so rigid. Very nice to look at, especially with his shirt off."

ðə bɔlz spʌn fjʊɹiəsli. "aɪ sɝɾənli hæv noʊ dɪzaɪɝ tə lʊk ət ɡɑləd, wɪð əɹ wɪθaʊɾ ɪz ʃɝt."

The balls spun furiously. "I certainly have no desire to look at Galad, with or without his shirt."

"aɪ ʃʊdn tiz ju," mɪn sɛd kɑntʃɹɪtli. "aɪm sɑɹi fəɹ ðæt. bʌt jə də laɪk tə lʊk əɾ ɪm - doʊnt ɡɹɪmɑs ət mi laɪk ðət - ən soʊ dʌz nɪɹli ɛvɹi wʊmən ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ u ɪzən ə ɹɛd. aɪv sin ɛɛs sədaɪ daʊn ət ðə pɹæktəs jɑɹdz wən hiz wɝkɪŋ fɔɹmz, ɪspɛʃli ɡɹinz. tʃɛkɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ wɔɹɾɝz, ðeɪ seɪ, bʌɾ aɪ doʊn si soʊ mɛni wən ɡɑləɾ ɪzən ðɛɹ. ivən ðə kʊks ən meɪdz kʌm aʊt tə wɑtʃ hɪm."

"I shouldn't tease you," Min said contritely. "I'm sorry for that. But you do like to look at him - don't grimace at me like that - and so does nearly every woman in the White Tower who isn't a Red. I've seen Aes Sedai down at the practice yards when he's working forms, especially Greens. Checking on their Warders, they say, but I don't see so many when Galad isn't there. Even the cooks and maids come out to watch him."

ðə bɔlz stɑp dɛd, ən fəɹ ə moʊmən ɛɡwin stɛɹɾ ət ðɛm. ðeɪ vænɪʃt. sʌɾənli ʃi ɡɪɡəld. "hi ɪz ɡʊd-lʊkɪŋ, ɪzən hi? ivən wən i wɔks i lʊks əz ɪf hiz dænsɪŋ." ðə kʌlɝ ɪn əɹ tʃiks dipənd. "aɪ noʊ aɪ ʃʊdn stɛɹ ət hɪm, bʌɾ aɪ kæn hɛlp maɪsɛlf."

The balls stopped dead, and for a moment Egwene stared at them. They vanished. Suddenly she giggled. "He is good-looking, isn't he? Even when he walks he looks as if he's dancing." The color in her cheeks deepened. "I know I shouldn't stare at him, but I can't help myself."

"aɪ kæn iðɝ," mɪn sɛd, "æn aɪ kən si wʌt hiz laɪk."

"I can't either," Min said, "and I can see what he is like."

"bʌɾ ɪf hiz ɡʊd - ?"

"But if he is good - ?"

"ɛɡwin, ɡɑləɾ ɪz soʊ ɡʊd hid meɪk jə tɛɹ jəɹ hɛɹ aʊt. hid hɝɾ ə pɝsən kəz i hæd tə sɝv ə ɡɹeɪɾɝ ɡʊd. hi wʊdn ivən noʊɾəs u wɑz hɝt, kəz hid bi soʊ ɪntɛn ɑn ði ʌðɝ, bʌɾ ɪf i dɪd, hi wəɾ ɪkspɛkt əm tə ʌndɝstæn ən θɪŋk ɪt wɑz ɔl wɛl ən ɹaɪt."

"Egwene, Galad is so good he'd make you tear your hair out. He'd hurt a person because he had to serve a greater good. He wouldn't even notice who was hurt, because he'd be so intent on the other, but if he did, he would expect them to understand and think it was all well and right."

"aɪ səpoʊz jə noʊ," ɛɡwin sɛd. ʃi hæd sin mɪnz əbɪləɾi tə lʊk ət pipəl ən ɹɛɾ ɔl sɔɹts ə θɪŋz əbaʊt ðɛm; mɪn dɪd nɑt tɛl ɛvɹiθɪŋ ʃi sɔ, ən ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ɔlweɪz si ɛniθɪŋ, bʌt ðəɹ hæd bɪn ɪnʌf fəɹ ɛɡwin tə bɪliv. ʃi ɡlænst ət nɪneɪiv - ði ʌðɝ wʊmən wɑz stɪl peɪsɪŋ, mʌɾɝɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf - ðən ɹitʃt fəɹ seɪaɪdɑɹ əɡɛn ən ɹɪzumd əɹ dʒʌɡəlɪŋ ɪn ə dɛsəltɔɹi fæʃən.

"I suppose you know," Egwene said. She had seen Min's ability to look at people and read all sorts of things about them; Min did not tell everything she saw, and she did not always see anything, but there had been enough for Egwene to believe. She glanced at Nynaeve - the other woman was still pacing, muttering to herself - then reached for saidar again and resumed her juggling in a desultory fashion.

mɪn ʃɹʌɡd. "aɪ ɡɛs aɪ maɪɾ əz wɛl tɛl ju. hi dɪdn ivən noʊɾəs wʌɾ ɛls wɑz duɪŋ. hi æskt əɹ ɪf ʃi nu wɛðɝ jə maɪt bi wɔkɪŋ ðə saʊθ ɡɑɹɾən æftɝ sʌpɝ, sɪns tədeɪ ɪz ə fɹideɪ. aɪ fɛl sɑɹi fəɹ hɝ."

Min shrugged. "I guess I might as well tell you. He didn't even notice what Else was doing. He asked her if she knew whether you might be walking the South Garden after supper, since today is a freeday. I felt sorry for her."

"pʊɹ ɛls," ɛɡwin mɝmɝd, ən ðə bɔlz ə laɪt bɪkeɪm mɔɹ laɪvli əbʌv əɹ hænz. mɪn læft.

"Poor Else," Egwene murmured, and the balls of light became more lively above her hands. Min laughed.

ðə dɔɹ bæŋd oʊpən, kɑt baɪ ðə wɪnd. ɛɡwin ɡeɪv ə jɛlp ən lɛt ðə bɔlz vænɪʃ bɪfɔɹ ʃi sɔ ɪt wɑz oʊnli ɪleɪn.

The door banged open, caught by the wind. Egwene gave a yelp and let the balls vanish before she saw it was only Elayne.

ðə ɡoʊldən-hɛɹd dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ʌv ændɝ pʊʃt ðə dɔɹ ʃʌɾ ən hʌŋ ʌp əɹ kloʊk ɑn ə pɛɡ. "aɪ dʒʌs hɝd," ʃi sɛd. "ðə ɹumɝz ɑɹ tʃɹu. kɪŋ ɡɔlʒɹiən ɪz dɛd. ðət meɪks ɪɾ ə wɔɹ ə səksɛʃən."

The golden-haired Daughter-Heir of Andor pushed the door shut and hung up her cloak on a peg. "I just heard," she said. "The rumors are true. King Galldrian is dead. That makes it a war of succession."

mɪn snɔɹɾɪd. "sɪvəl wɔɹ. wɔɹ ə səksɛʃən. ə lɑɾ ə sɪli neɪmz fəɹ ðə seɪm θɪŋ. dʒju maɪn ɪf wi doʊn tɔk əbaʊɾ ɪt? ðæts ɔl wi hɪɹ. wɔɹ ɪn kɛɹhin. wɔɹ ɑn toʊmən hɛd. ðeɪ meɪ hæv kɑt ðə fɔls dʒɹæɡən ɪn sɑldɑiə, bʌt ðɛɹz stɪl wɔɹ ɪn tɛɹ. moʊst ʌv ɪts ɹumɝz, ɛniweɪ. jɛstɝdeɪ, aɪ hɝd wʌn ə ðə kʊks seɪɪŋ ʃid hɝɾ ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ wɑz mɑɹtʃɪŋ ɑn tæntʃəkoʊ. ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ!"

Min snorted. "Civil war. War of succession. A lot of silly names for the same thing. Do you mind if we don't talk about it? That's all we hear. War in Cairhien. War on Toman Head. They may have caught the false Dragon in Saldaea, but there's still war in Tear. Most of it is rumors, anyway. Yesterday, I heard one of the cooks saying she'd heard Artur Hawkwing was marching on Tanchico. Artur Hawkwing!"

"aɪ θɔt jə dɪd nɑt wɑnə tɔk əbaʊɾ ɪt," ɛɡwin sɛd.

"I thought you did not want to talk about it," Egwene said.

"aɪ sɔ lɑɡən," ɪleɪn sɛd. "hi wɑz sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ə bɛntʃ ɪn ði ɪnɝ kɔɹt, kɹaɪɪŋ. hi ɹæn wən i sɔ mi. aɪ kænɑt hɛlp filɪŋ sɑɹi fəɹ hɪm."

"I saw Logain," Elayne said. "He was sitting on a bench in the Inner Court, crying. He ran when he saw me. I cannot help feeling sorry for him."

"bɛɾɝ i kɹaɪz ðən ðə ɹɛst ʌv ʌs, ɪleɪn," mɪn sɛd.

"Better he cries than the rest of us, Elayne," Min said.

"aɪ noʊ wʌɾ i ɪz," ɪleɪn sɛd kɑmli. "ɔɹ ɹæðɝ, wʌɾ i wɑz. hi ɪzən ɛnimɔɹ, ən aɪ kən fil sɑɹi fəɹ hɪm."

"I know what he is," Elayne said calmly. "Or rather, what he was. He isn't anymore, and I can feel sorry for him."

ɛɡwin slʌmp bæk əɡɛns ðə wɔl. ɹænd. lɑɡən ɔlweɪz meɪɾ əɹ θɪŋk ə ɹænd. ʃi hæd nɑt dʒɹimd əbaʊɾ ɪm ɪn mʌnθs, naʊ, nɑt ðə kaɪndə dʒɹimz ʃi hæd hæɾ ɑn ðə ɹɪvɝ kwin. æneɪjə stɪl meɪɾ əɹ ɹaɪt daʊn ɛvɹiθɪŋ ʃi dʒɹimd, ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tʃɛkt əm fəɹ saɪnz, əɹ kənɛkʃənz tə ɪvɛns, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz nɛvɝ ɛniθɪŋ əbaʊt ɹænd ɪksɛp dʒɹimz ðæt, æneɪjə sɛd, mɛnt ʃi mɪs hɪm. ɑdli, ʃi fɛlt ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf i wɝ nɑt ðəɹ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ, əz ɪf i hæd sis tə ɪɡzɪst, əlɔŋ wɪð əɹ dʒɹimz, ə fju wiks æftɝ ɹitʃɪŋ ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ən aɪ sɪt θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt haʊ naɪsli ɡɑləd wɔks, ʃi θɔt bɪɾɝli. ɹænd əz tə bi ɔl ɹaɪt. ɪf hid bɪn kɑɾ ən dʒɛntəld, aɪɾ əv hɝd sʌmθɪŋ.

Egwene slumped back against the wall. Rand. Logain always made her think of Rand. She had not dreamed about him in months, now, not the kind of dreams she had had on the River Queen. Anaiya still made her write down everything she dreamed, and the Aes Sedai checked them for signs, or connections to events, but there was never anything about Rand except dreams that, Anaiya said, meant she missed him. Oddly, she felt almost as if he were not there any longer, as if he had ceased to exist, along with her dreams, a few weeks after reaching the White Tower. And I sit thinking about how nicely Galad walks, she thought bitterly. Rand has to be all right. If he'd been caught and gentled, I'd have heard something.

ðət sɛn ə tʃɪl θɹu hɝ, əz ɪt nɛvɝ feɪl tə du, ðə θɔɾ ə ɹænd biɪŋ dʒɛntəld, ɹænd wipɪŋ ən wɑntɪŋ tə daɪ əz lɑɡən dɪd.

That sent a chill through her, as it never failed to do, the thought of Rand being gentled, Rand weeping and wanting to die as Logain did.

ɪleɪn sæt daʊn bɪsaɪɾ əɹ ɑn ðə bɛd, tʌkɪŋ əɹ fiɾ ʌp ʌndɝ hɝ. "ɪf jə ɑɹ munɪŋ oʊvɝ ɡɑləd, ɛɡwin, jəl əv noʊ sɪmpəθi fɹəm mi. əl əv nɪneɪiv doʊs jə wɪð wʌn ə ðoʊz hɔɹəbəl kənkɑkʃənz ʃiz ɔlweɪz tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt." ʃi fɹaʊn ət nɪneɪiv, hu hæd teɪkən noʊ noʊɾəs ə hɝ ɛntʃɹəns. "wʌɾ ɪz ðə mæɾɝ wɪð hɝ? doʊn tɛl mi ʃiz stɑɹɾəd saɪɪŋ æftɝ ɡɑləd, tu!"

Elayne sat down beside her on the bed, tucking her feet up under her. "If you are mooning over Galad, Egwene, you will have no sympathy from me. I'll have Nynaeve dose you with one of those horrible concoctions she's always talking about." She frowned at Nynaeve, who had taken no notice of her entrance. "What is the matter with her? Don't tell me she has started sighing after Galad, too!"

"aɪ wʊdn bɑðɝ hɝ." mɪn lin təwɔɹd ðə tu ʌv əm ən loʊɝɾ əɹ vɔɪs. "ðæt skɪni æksɛptɪɾ aɪɹɛlə toʊld əɹ ʃi wɑz əz klʌmzi əz ə kaʊ ən hæd hæf ðə tæləns, ən nɪneɪiv klaʊuɾəd əɹ ɪɹ." ɪleɪn wɪnst. "ɪɡzækli," mɪn mɝmɝd. "ðeɪ hæɾ əɹ ʌp tə ʃɛɹiəmz stʌɾi bɪfɔɹ jə kəd blɪŋk, ən ʃi hæzən bɪn fɪt tə lɪv wɪð sɪns."

"I wouldn't bother her." Min leaned toward the two of them and lowered her voice. "That skinny Accepted Irella told her she was as clumsy as a cow and had half the Talents, and Nynaeve clouted her ear." Elayne winced. "Exactly," Min murmured. "They had her up to Sheriam's study before you could blink, and she hasn't been fit to live with since."

əpɛɹənli mɪn hæd nɑt dʒɹɑpt əɹ vɔɪs ɪnʌf, fəɹ ðəɹ wɑz ə ɡɹaʊl fɹəm nɪneɪiv. sʌɾənli ðə dɔɹ wɪpt oʊpən wʌns mɔɹ, ən ə ɡeɪl haʊld ɪndə ðə ɹum. ɪt dɪd nɑt ɹʌfəl ðə blæŋkəts ɑn ɛɡwinz bɛd, bʌt mɪn ən ðə stul tɑpəld, tə ɹoʊl əɡɛns ðə wɔl. ɪmiɾiətli ðə wɪn daɪd, ən nɪneɪiv stʊd wɪð ə stʃɹɪkən lʊk ɑn əɹ feɪs.

Apparently Min had not dropped her voice enough, for there was a growl from Nynaeve. Suddenly the door whipped open once more, and a gale howled into the room. It did not ruffle the blankets on Egwene's bed, but Min and the stool toppled, to roll against the wall. Immediately the wind died, and Nynaeve stood with a stricken look on her face.

ɛɡwin hɝid tə ðə dɔɹ ən pikt aʊt. ðə nundeɪ sʌn wɑz bɝnɪŋ ɔf ðə læst ɹimaɪndɝz ə læs naɪts ɹeɪnstɔɹm. ðə stɪl-dæmp bælkəni ɝaʊn ðə nɑvəsɪz' kɔɹt wɑz ɛmpti, ðə lɔŋ ɹoʊ ʌv dɔɹz tə nɑvəsɪz' ɹumz ɔl ʃʌt. ðə nɑvəsɪz u hæd teɪkən ædvæntɪdʒ ə ðə fɹideɪ tə ɛndʒɔɪ ðɛmsɛlvz ɪn ðə ɡɑɹɾənz wɝ noʊ daʊt kætʃɪŋ ʌp ɑn ðɛɹ slip. noʊ wʌn kəɾ əv sin. ʃi kloʊz ðə dɔɹ ən tʊk əɹ pleɪs bɪsaɪɾ ɪleɪn əɡɛn əz nɪneɪiv hɛlp mɪn tə hɝ fit.

Egwene hurried to the door and peeked out. The noonday sun was burning off the last reminders of last night's rainstorm. The still-damp balcony around the Novices' Court was empty, the long row of doors to novices' rooms all shut. The novices who had taken advantage of the freeday to enjoy themselves in the gardens were no doubt catching up on their sleep. No one could have seen. She closed the door and took her place beside Elayne again as Nynaeve helped Min to her feet.

"aɪm sɑɹi, mɪn," nɪneɪiv sɛɾ ɪn ə taɪt vɔɪs. "səmtaɪmz maɪ tɛmpɝ. . . . aɪ kæn æsk jə tə fɝɡɪv mi, nɑt fəɹ ðɪs." ʃi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. "ɪf jə wɑnə ɹipɔɹt mi tə ʃɛɹiəm, əl ʌndɝstænd. aɪ dɪzɝv ɪt."

"I'm sorry, Min," Nynaeve said in a tight voice. "Sometimes my temper. . . . I can't ask you to forgive me, not for this." She took a deep breath. "If you want to report me to Sheriam, I will understand. I deserve it."

ɛɡwin wɪʃt ʃi hæd nɑt hɝd ðəɾ ædmɪʃən; nɪneɪiv kəd ɡɹoʊ pɹɪkli oʊvɝ sətʃ θɪŋz. sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ ɑn wɪtʃ tə foʊkəs, sʌmθɪŋ nɪneɪiv kəd bɪliv ʃi hæd hæɾ əɹ ətɛnʃən ɑn, ʃi faʊn hɝsɛlf tʌtʃɪŋ seɪaɪdɑɹ wʌns mɔɹ, ən bɪɡæn dʒʌɡəlɪŋ ðə bɔlz ə laɪɾ əɡɛn. ɪleɪn kwɪkli dʒɔɪn hɝ; ɛɡwin sɔ ðə ɡloʊ fɔɹm ɝaʊn ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ivən bɪfɔɹ θɹi taɪni bɔlz əpɪɹɾ əbʌv əɹ hænz. ðeɪ bɪɡæn tə pæs ðə lɪɾəl ɡloʊɪŋ sfɪɹz bæk ən fɔɹθ ɪn ɪnkɹisɪŋli ɪntʃɹəkət pæɾɝnz. səmtaɪmz wʌn wɪŋkt aʊɾ əz wʌn ɡɝl əɹ ði ʌðɝ feɪl tə meɪnteɪn ɪɾ əz ɪt keɪm tə hɝ, ðən wɪŋk bæk ə lɪɾəl ɔltɝɾ ɪn kʌlɝ əɹ saɪz.

Egwene wished she had not heard that admission; Nynaeve could grow prickly over such things. Searching for something on which to focus, something Nynaeve could believe she had had her attention on, she found herself touching saidar once more, and began juggling the balls of light again. Elayne quickly joined her; Egwene saw the glow form around the Daughter-Heir even before three tiny balls appeared above her hands. They began to pass the little glowing spheres back and forth in increasingly intricate patterns. Sometimes one winked out as one girl or the other failed to maintain it as it came to her, then winked back a little altered in color or size.

ðə wʌn paʊɝ fɪld ɛɡwin wɪð laɪf. ʃi smɛl ðə feɪn ɹoʊz ɝoʊmə ʌv soʊp fɹəm ɪleɪnz mɔɹnɪŋ bæθ. ʃi kəd fil ðə ɹʌf plæstɝ ə ðə wɔlz, ðə smuð stoʊnz ə ðə flɔɹ, əz wɛl əz ʃi kəd ðə bɛd wɛɹ ʃi sæt. ʃi kəd hɪɹ mɪn ən nɪneɪiv bɹið, mʌtʃ lɛs ðɛɹ kwaɪət wɝdz.

The One Power filled Egwene with life. She smelled the faint rose aroma of soap from Elayne's morning bath. She could feel the rough plaster of the walls, the smooth stones of the floor, as well as she could the bed where she sat. She could hear Min and Nynaeve breathe, much less their quiet words.

"ɪf ɪt kʌmz tə fɝɡɪvɪŋ," mɪn sɛd, "meɪbi jə ʃəd fɝɡɪv mi. juv ə tɛmpɝ, ən aɪ hæv ə bɪɡ maʊθ. əl fɝɡɪv jə ɪf jə fɝɡɪv mi." wɪð mɝmɝz ʌv "fɝɡɪvən" ðət saʊndəd mɛn ɑn boʊθ saɪdz, ðə tu wɪmən hʌɡd. "bʌɾ ɪf jə də ɪɾ əɡɛn," mɪn sɛd wɪð ə læf, "aɪ maɪt klaʊt jəɹ ɪɹ."

"If it comes to forgiving," Min said, "maybe you should forgive me. You have a temper, and I have a big mouth. I will forgive you if you forgive me." With murmurs of "forgiven" that sounded meant on both sides, the two women hugged. "But if you do it again," Min said with a laugh, "I might clout your ear."

"nɛks taɪm," nɪneɪiv ɹɪplaɪd, "aɪ wɪl θɹoʊ sʌmθɪŋ ət ju." ʃi wɑz læfɪŋ, tu, bʌɾ əɹ læftɝ sist əbɹʌpli əz əɹ aɪ fɛl ɑn ɛɡwin ən ɪleɪn. "ju tu stɑp ðæt, əɹ ðəɹ wɪl bi sʌmwʌn ɡoʊɪŋ tə ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz. tu sʌmoʊnz."

"Next time," Nynaeve replied, "I will throw something at you." She was laughing, too, but her laughter ceased abruptly as her eye fell on Egwene and Elayne. "You two stop that, or there will be someone going to the Mistress of Novices. Two someones."

"nɪneɪiv, jə wʊdnt!" ɛɡwin pɹətɛstəd. wən ʃi sɔ ðə lʊk ɪn nɪneɪivz aɪz, ðoʊ, ʃi heɪstəli sɛvɝɾ ɔl kɑntækt wɪð seɪaɪdɑɹ. "vɛɹi wɛl. aɪ bɪliv ju. ðɛɹz noʊ nid tə pɹuv ɪt."

"Nynaeve, you wouldn't!" Egwene protested. When she saw the look in Nynaeve's eyes, though, she hastily severed all contact with saidar. "Very well. I believe you. There's no need to prove it."

"wi hæv tə pɹæktəs," ɪleɪn sɛd. "ðeɪ æsk mɔɹ ən mɔɹ ʌv ʌs. ɪf wi dɪd nɑt pɹæktəs ɑn əɹ oʊn, wi wəd nɛvɝ kip ʌp." hɝ feɪs ʃoʊd kɑm kəmpoʊʒɝ, bʌt ʃi hæd lɛt ɡoʊ ʌv seɪaɪdɑɹ əz heɪstəli əz ɛɡwin hɝsɛlf hæd.

"We have to practice," Elayne said. "They ask more and more of us. If we did not practice on our own, we would never keep up." Her face showed calm composure, but she had let go of saidar as hastily as Egwene herself had.

"ænd wʌt hæpənz wən jə dʒɹɔ tu mʌtʃ," nɪneɪiv æskt, "æn ðɛɹz noʊ wʌn ðəɹ tə stɑp ju? aɪ wɪʃ jə wɝ mɔɹ əfɹeɪd. aɪ æm. doʊn jə θɪŋk aɪ noʊ wʌɾ ɪts laɪk fəɹ ju? ɪts ɔlweɪz ðɛɹ, ən jə wɑnə fɪl jɝsɛlf wɪð ɪt. səmtaɪmz ɪts ɔl aɪ kən də tə meɪk maɪsɛlf stɑp; aɪ wɑn ɔl ʌv ɪt. aɪ noʊ ɪt wəd bɝn mi tə ə kɹɪsp, ən aɪ wɑn ɪɾ ɛniweɪ." ʃi ʃɪvɝd. "aɪ dʒʌst wɪʃ jə wɝ mɔɹ əfɹeɪd."

"And what happens when you draw too much," Nynaeve asked, "and there's no one there to stop you? I wish you were more afraid. I am. Don't you think I know what it is like for you? It's always there, and you want to fill yourself with it. Sometimes it is all I can do to make myself stop; I want all of it. I know it would burn me to a crisp, and I want it anyway." She shivered. "I just wish you were more afraid."

"aɪ æm əfɹeɪd," ɛɡwin sɛd wɪð ə saɪ. "aɪm tɛɹəfaɪd. bʌɾ ɪt dʌzn sim tə hɛlp. wʌɾ əbaʊt ju, ɪleɪn?"

"I am afraid," Egwene said with a sigh. "I'm terrified. But it doesn't seem to help. What about you, Elayne?"

"ði oʊnli θɪŋ ðət tɛɹəfaɪz mi," ɪleɪn sɛɾ ɛɹəli, "ɪz wɑʃɪŋ dɪʃəz. ɪt simz əz ɪf aɪ hæv tə wɑʃ dɪʃəz ɛvɹi deɪ." ɛɡwin θɹu hɝ pɪloʊ ət hɝ. ɪleɪn pʊld ɪɾ ɔf əɹ hɛɾ ən θɹu ɪt bæk, bʌt ðən əɹ ʃoʊldɝz slʌmpt. "oʊ, vɛɹi wɛl. aɪm soʊ skɛɹɾ aɪ doʊnt noʊ waɪ maɪ tiθ ɑɹ nɑt tʃæɾɝɪŋ. ɪleɪɾə toʊl mi aɪd bi soʊ fɹaɪɾənd ðəɾ aɪ wəd wɑnə ɹʌn əweɪ wɪð ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ pipəl, bʌɾ aɪ dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd. ə mæn u dʒɹoʊv ɑksən əz hɑɹɾ əz ðeɪ dʒɹaɪv əs wəd bi ʃʌnd. aɪm taɪɝɾ ɔl ðə taɪm. aɪ weɪk ʌp taɪɝɾ ən ɡoʊ tə bɛɾ ɪɡzɔstəd, ən səmtaɪmz aɪm soʊ əfɹeɪd ðəɾ əl slɪp ən tʃænəl mɔɹ ə ðə paʊɝ ðən aɪ kən hændəl ðəɾ aɪ. . . ." piɹɪŋ ɪndə hɝ læp, ʃi lɛt ðə wɝdz tʃɹeɪl ɔf.

"The only thing that terrifies me," Elayne said airily, "is washing dishes. It seems as if I have to wash dishes every day." Egwene threw her pillow at her. Elayne pulled it off her head and threw it back, but then her shoulders slumped. "Oh, very well. I am so scared I don't know why my teeth are not chattering. Elaida told me I'd be so frightened that I would want to run away with the Traveling People, but I did not understand. A man who drove oxen as hard as they drive us would be shunned. I am tired all the time. I wake up tired and go to bed exhausted, and sometimes I'm so afraid that I will slip and channel more of the Power than I can handle that I. . . ." Peering into her lap, she let the words trail off.

ɛɡwin nu wʌt ʃi hæd nɑt spoʊkən. ðɛɹ ɹumz leɪ ɹaɪt nɛks tə itʃ ʌðɝ, ən əz ɪn mɛni ʌv ðə nɑvəs ɹumz, ə smɔl hoʊl hæd lɔŋ əɡoʊ bɪn bɔɹd θɹu ðə wɔl bɪtwin, tu smɔl tə bi sin ənlɛs jə nu wɛɹ tə lʊk, bʌt jusfəl fəɹ tɔk æftɝ ðə læmps wɝ ɪkstɪŋɡwɪʃt, wən ðə ɡɝlz kəd nɑt liv ðɛɹ ɹumz. ɛɡwin hæd hɝɾ ɪleɪn kɹaɪɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə slip mɔɹ ðən wʌns, ən ʃi hæd noʊ daʊt ðəɾ ɪleɪn hæd hɝɾ əɹ oʊn kɹaɪɪŋ.

Egwene knew what she had not spoken. Their rooms lay right next to each other, and as in many of the novice rooms, a small hole had long ago been bored through the wall between, too small to be seen unless you knew where to look, but useful for talk after the lamps were extinguished, when the girls could not leave their rooms. Egwene had heard Elayne crying herself to sleep more than once, and she had no doubt that Elayne had heard her own crying.

"ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ pipəl ɑɹ tɛmptɪŋ," nɪneɪiv əɡɹid, "bʌt wɛɹɛvɝ jə ɡoʊ, ɪɾəl nɑt tʃeɪnʒ wʌt jə kən du. jə kænɑt ɹʌn fɹəm seɪaɪdɑɹ." ʃi dɪd nɑt saʊn əz ɪf ʃi laɪkt wʌt ʃi wɑz seɪɪŋ.

"The Traveling People are tempting," Nynaeve agreed, "but wherever you go, it will not change what you can do. You cannot run from saidar." She did not sound as if she liked what she was saying.

"wʌt dʒju si, mɪn?" ɪleɪn sɛd. "ɑɹ wi ɔl gɑnə bi paʊɝfəl ɛɛs sədaɪ, əɹ wɪl wi spɛn ðə ɹɛst ʌv əɹ lɪvz wɑʃɪŋ dɪʃəz əz nɑvəsɪz, ɔɹ. . . ." ʃi ʃɹʌɡd ənkʌmftəbli əz ɪf ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə vɔɪs ðə θɝɾ ɔltɝnəɾɪv ðət keɪm tə maɪnd. sɛn hoʊm. pʊɾ aʊɾ ə ðə taʊɝ. tu nɑvəsɪz hæd bɪn pʊɾ aʊt sɪns ɛɡwin keɪm, ən ɛvɹiwʌn spoʊk ə ðɛm ɪn wɪspɝz, əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ dɛd.

"What do you see, Min?" Elayne said. "Are we all going to be powerful Aes Sedai, or will we spend the rest of our lives washing dishes as novices, or. . . ." She shrugged uncomfortably as if she did not want to voice the third alternative that came to mind. Sent home. Put out of the Tower. Two novices had been put out since Egwene came, and everyone spoke of them in whispers, as if they were dead.

mɪn ʃɪftəɾ ɑn əɹ stul. "aɪ doʊn laɪk ɹiɾɪŋ fɹɛnz," ʃi mʌɾɝd. "fɹɛndʃɪp ɡɛts ɪn ðə weɪ ʌv ðə ɹɛɾɪŋ. ɪt meɪks mi tʃɹaɪ tə pʊt ðə bɛs feɪs ɑn wʌɾ aɪ si. ðæts waɪ aɪ doʊn də ɪt fəɹ jə θɹi ɛnimɔɹ. ɛniweɪ, nʌθɪŋ əz tʃeɪnʒd əbaʊt jə ðəɾ aɪ kæn. . . ." ʃi skwɪntɪɾ ət ðɛm, ən sʌɾənli fɹaʊnd. "ðæts nu," ʃi bɹiðd.

Min shifted on her stool. "I don't like reading friends," she muttered. "Friendship gets in the way of the reading. It makes me try to put the best face on what I see. That's why I don't do it for you three anymore. Anyway, nothing has changed about you that I can. . . ." She squinted at them, and suddenly frowned. "That's new," she breathed.

"wʌt?" nɪneɪiv æskt ʃɑɹpli.

"What?" Nynaeve asked sharply.

mɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd bɪfɔɹ ænsɝɪŋ. "deɪnʒɝ. jə ɑɹ ɔl ɪn səm kaɪndə deɪnʒɝ. əɹ jəl bi, vɛɹi sun. aɪ kæn meɪk ɪɾ aʊt, bʌɾ ɪts deɪnʒɝ."

Min hesitated before answering. "Danger. You are all in some kind of danger. Or you will be, very soon. I can't make it out, but it is danger."

"ju si," nɪneɪiv sɛd tə ðə tu ɡɝlz sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə bɛd. "ju mʌs teɪk kɛɹ. wi ɔl mʌst. jə mʌs boʊθ pɹɑməs nɑt tə tʃænəl əɡɛn wɪθaʊt sʌmwʌn tə ɡaɪd ju."

"You see," Nynaeve said to the two girls sitting on the bed. "You must take care. We all must. You must both promise not to channel again without someone to guide you."

"aɪ doʊnt wɑnə tɔk əbaʊɾ ɪɾ ɛnimɔɹ," ɛɡwin sɛd.

"I don't want to talk about it anymore," Egwene said.

ɪleɪn nɑɾəd iɡɝli. "jɛs. lɛts tɔk əbaʊt sʌmθɪŋ ɛls. mɪn, ɪf jə pʊɾ ɑn ə dʒɹɛs, əl weɪdʒɝ ɡɔɪn wəɾ æsk jə tə ɡoʊ wɔkɪŋ wɪð hɪm. jə noʊ hiz bɪn lʊkɪŋ ət ju, bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk ðə bɹitʃɪz ən ðə mænz koʊt pʊɾ ɪm ɔf."

Elayne nodded eagerly. "Yes. Let's talk about something else. Min, if you put on a dress, I'll wager Gawyn would ask you to go walking with him. You know he's been looking at you, but I think the breeches and the man's coat put him off."

"aɪ dʒɹɛs ðə weɪ aɪ laɪk, ən aɪ woʊn tʃeɪnʒ fəɹ ə lɔɹd, ivən ɪf hiz jəɹ bɹʌðɝ." mɪn spoʊk æbsənli, stɪl skwɪntɪŋ əɾ əm ən fɹaʊnɪŋ; ɪt wɑz ə kɑnvɝseɪʃən ðeɪ hæd hæd bɪfɔɹ. "səmtaɪmz ɪts jusfəl tə pæs əz ə bɔɪ."

"I dress the way I like, and I won't change for a lord, even if he is your brother." Min spoke absently, still squinting at them and frowning; it was a conversation they had had before. "Sometimes it is useful to pass as a boy."

"noʊ wʌn u lʊks twaɪs bɪlivz jə ɑɹ ə bɔɪ." ɪleɪn smaɪld.

"No one who looks twice believes you are a boy." Elayne smiled.

ɛɡwin wɑz ənkʌmftəɹbəl. ɪleɪn wɑz fɔɹsɪŋ ə sɛmbləns ʌv ɡeɪəɾi, mɪn wɑz hɑɹdli peɪɪŋ ətɛnʃən, ən nɪneɪiv lʊkt əz ɪf ʃi wɑntəd tə wɔɹn əm əɡɛn.

Egwene was uncomfortable. Elayne was forcing a semblance of gaiety, Min was hardly paying attention, and Nynaeve looked as if she wanted to warn them again.

wən ðə dɔɹ swʌŋ oʊpən wʌns mɔɹ, ɛɡwin baʊndəd tə hɝ fit tə kloʊz ɪt, ɡɹeɪtfəl fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ tə də bɪsaɪdz wɑtʃ ði ʌðɝz pɹitɛnd. bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɹitʃt ɪt, ðoʊ, ə dɑɹk-aɪɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪð əɹ blɑn hɛɹ dʌn ɪn ə mʌltətuɾ ə bɹeɪdz stɛpt ɪndə ðə ɹum. ɛɡwin blɪŋkt ɪn sɝpɹaɪz, əz mʌtʃ əɾ ɪt biɪŋ ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ əz ət liɑnʒɹɪn. ʃi hæd nɑt hɝd ðət liɑnʒɹɪn hæd ɹɪtɝn tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, bʌt bɪɑn ðæt, nɑvəsɪz wɝ sɛn fəɹ ɪf ən ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑntəd ðɛm; ɪt kəd min noʊ ɡʊd, ə sɪstɝ kʌmɪŋ hɝsɛlf.

When the door swung open once more, Egwene bounded to her feet to close it, grateful for something to do besides watch the others pretend. Before she reached it, though, a dark-eyed Aes Sedai with her blond hair done in a multitude of braids stepped into the room. Egwene blinked in surprise, as much at it being any Aes Sedai as at Liandrin. She had not heard that Liandrin had returned to the White Tower, but beyond that, novices were sent for if an Aes Sedai wanted them; it could mean no good, a sister coming herself.

ðə ɹum wɑz kɹaʊɾəd wɪð faɪv wɪmən ɪn ɪt. liɑnʒɹɪn pɔz tə ədʒʌst əɹ ɹɛd-fɹɪnd ʃɔl, aɪɪŋ ðɛm. mɪn dɪd nɑt muv, bʌɾ ɪleɪn ɹoʊz, ən ðə θɹi stændɪŋ kɝtsid, ðoʊ nɪneɪiv bɛɹli flɛkst əɹ ni. ɛɡwin dɪd nɑt θɪŋk nɪneɪiv wəɾ ɛvɝ ɡɹoʊ juz tə hævɪŋ ʌðɝz ɪn əθɔɹəɾi oʊvɝ hɝ.

The room was crowded with five women in it. Liandrin paused to adjust her red-fringed shawl, eyeing them. Min did not move, but Elayne rose, and the three standing curtsied, though Nynaeve barely flexed her knee. Egwene did not think Nynaeve would ever grow used to having others in authority over her.

liɑnʒɹɪnz aɪz sɛɾəld ɑn nɪneɪiv. "ænd waɪ ɑɹ jə hɪɹ, ɪn ðə nɑvəsɪz' kɔɹɾɝz, tʃaɪld?" hɝ toʊn wɑz aɪs.

Liandrin's eyes settled on Nynaeve. "And why are you here, in the novices' quarters, child?" Her tone was ice.

"aɪ æm vɪzəɾɪŋ wɪð fɹɛnz," nɪneɪiv sɛɾ ɪn ə taɪt vɔɪs. æftɝ ə moʊmənt ʃi æɾəd ə bɪleɪɾɪd, "liɑnʒɹɪn sədaɪ."

"I am visiting with friends," Nynaeve said in a tight voice. After a moment she added a belated, "Liandrin Sedai."

"ði æksɛptɪd, ðeɪ kən əv noʊ fɹɛnz əmʌŋ ðə nɑvəsɪz. ðɪs jə ʃʊɾə lɝn baɪ ðɪs taɪm, tʃaɪld. bʌɾ ɪts əz wɛl ðəɾ aɪ faɪn jə hɪɹ. jə ən ju" - hɝ fɪŋɡɝ stæbd əɾ ɪleɪn ən mɪn - "wɪl ɡoʊ."

"The Accepted, they can have no friends among the novices. This you should have learned by this time, child. But it is as well that I find you here. You and you" - her finger stabbed at Elayne and Min - "will go."

"aɪ wɪl ɹɪtɝn leɪɾɝ." mɪn ɹoʊz kæʒəwəli, meɪkɪŋ ə ɡɹeɪt ʃoʊ ʌv biɪŋ ɪn noʊ hɝi tə oʊbeɪ, ən stʃɹoʊl baɪ liɑnʒɹɪn wɪð ə ɡɹɪn, ʌv wɪtʃ liɑnʒɹɪn tʊk noʊ noʊɾəs əɾ ɔl. ɪleɪn ɡeɪv ɛɡwin ən nɪneɪiv ə wɝid lʊk bɪfɔɹ ʃi dʒɹɑpt ə kɝtsi ən lɛft.

"I will return later." Min rose casually, making a great show of being in no hurry to obey, and strolled by Liandrin with a grin, of which Liandrin took no notice at all. Elayne gave Egwene and Nynaeve a worried look before she dropped a curtsy and left.

æftɝ ɪleɪn kloʊz ðə dɔɹ bɪhaɪn hɝ, liɑnʒɹɪn stʊd stʌɾiɪŋ ɛɡwin ən nɪneɪiv. ɛɡwin bɪɡæn tə fɪdʒɪɾ ʌndɝ ðə skɹuɾəni, bʌt nɪneɪiv hɛl hɝsɛlf stʃɹeɪt, wɪð oʊnli ə lɪɾəl haɪɾənɪŋ ə hɝ kʌlɝ.

After Elayne closed the door behind her, Liandrin stood studying Egwene and Nynaeve. Egwene began to fidget under the scrutiny, but Nynaeve held herself straight, with only a little heightening of her color.

"ju tu ɑɹ fɹəm ðə seɪm vɪlədʒ əz ðə bɔɪz u tʃɹævəld wɪð mɔɪɹeɪn. ɪz ɪt nɑt soʊ?" liɑnʒɹɪn sɛd sʌɾənli.

"You two are from the same village as the boys who traveled with Moiraine. Is it not so?" Liandrin said suddenly.

"du juv səm wɝɾ ə ɹænd?" ɛɡwin æskt iɡɝli. liɑnʒɹɪn ɑɹtʃt ən aɪbɹaʊ ət hɝ. "fɝɡɪv mi, ɛɛs sədaɪ. aɪ fɝɡɛt maɪsɛlf."

"Do you have some word of Rand?" Egwene asked eagerly. Liandrin arched an eyebrow at her. "Forgive me, Aes Sedai. I forget myself."

"hæv jə wɝɾ ə ðɛm?" nɪneɪiv sɛd, dʒʌst ʃɔɹɾ ʌv ə dɪmænd. ði æksɛptɪd hæd noʊ ɹul əbaʊt nɑt spikɪŋ tə ən ɛɛs sədaɪ əntɪl spoʊkən tə.

"Have you word of them?" Nynaeve said, just short of a demand. The Accepted had no rule about not speaking to an Aes Sedai until spoken to.

"ju hæv kənsɝn fəɹ ðɛm. ðəɾ ɪz ɡʊd. ðeɪ ɑɹ ɪn deɪnʒɝ, ən jə maɪt bi eɪbəl tə hɛlp ðɛm."

"You have concern for them. That is good. They are in danger, and you might be able to help them."

"haʊ dʒju noʊ ðəɹ ɪn tʃɹʌbəl?" ðəɹ wɑz noʊ daʊɾ əbaʊt ðə dɪmæn ɪn nɪneɪivz vɔɪs ðɪs taɪm.

"How do you know they're in trouble?" There was no doubt about the demand in Nynaeve's voice this time.

liɑnʒɹɪnz ɹoʊzbʌd maʊθ taɪɾənd, bʌɾ əɹ toʊn dɪd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ. "ðoʊ jə ɑɹ nɑɾ əwɛɹ ʌv ɪt, mɔɪɹeɪn əz sɛn lɛɾɝz tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ kənsɝnɪŋ ju. mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ, ʃi wɝiz əbaʊt ju, ən əbaʊt jəɹ jʌŋ . . . fɹɛnz. ðiz bɔɪz, ðeɪ ɑɹ ɪn deɪnʒɝ. dʒju wɪʃ tə hɛlp ðɛm, əɹ liv əm tə ðɛɹ feɪt?"

Liandrin's rosebud mouth tightened, but her tone did not change. "Though you are not aware of it, Moiraine has sent letters to the White Tower concerning you. Moiraine Sedai, she worries about you, and about your young . . . friends. These boys, they are in danger. Do you wish to help them, or leave them to their fate?"

"jɛs," ɛɡwin sɛd, ət ðə seɪm taɪm ðət nɪneɪiv sɛd, "wʌt kaɪndə tʃɹʌbəl? waɪ dʒju kɛɹ əbaʊt hɛlpɪŋ ðɛm?" nɪneɪiv ɡlænst ət ðə ɹɛd fɹɪnʒ ɑn liɑnʒɹɪnz ʃɔl. "æn aɪ θɔt jə dɪdn laɪk mɔɪɹeɪn."

"Yes," Egwene said, at the same time that Nynaeve said, "What kind of trouble? Why do you care about helping them?" Nynaeve glanced at the red fringe on Liandrin's shawl. "And I thought you didn't like Moiraine."

"du nɑt pɹɪzum tu mʌtʃ, tʃaɪld," liɑnʒɹɪn sɛd ʃɑɹpli. "tə bi æksɛptɪɾ ɪz nɑt tə bi ə sɪstɝ. æksɛptɪɾ ən nɑvəsɪz əlaɪk lɪsən wən ə sɪstɝ spiks, ən də əz ðeɪ ɑɹ toʊld." ʃi dʒɹu ə bɹɛθ ən wɛn ɑn; hɝ toʊn wɑz koʊldi sɝin əɡɛn, bʌɾ æŋɡɹi waɪt spɑts mɑɹɾ əɹ tʃiks. "sʌmdeɪ, aɪm ʃʊɹ, jəl sɝv ə kɑz, ən jəl lɝn ðən ðət tə sɝv ɪt jə mʌst wɝk ivən wɪð ðoʊz hum jə dɪslaɪk. aɪ tɛl jə aɪ hæv wɝkt wɪð mɛni wɪð hum aɪ wəd nɑt ʃɛɹ ə ɹum ɪf ɪt wɝ lɛf tə mi əloʊn. wəd jə nɑt wɝk əlɔŋsaɪd ðə wʌn jə heɪɾəd wɝst, ɪf ɪt wəd seɪv jəɹ fɹɛnz?"

"Do not presume too much, child," Liandrin said sharply. "To be Accepted is not to be a sister. Accepted and novices alike listen when a sister speaks, and do as they are told." She drew a breath and went on; her tone was coldy serene again, but angry white spots marred her cheeks. "Someday, I am sure, you will serve a cause, and you will learn then that to serve it you must work even with those whom you dislike. I tell you I have worked with many with whom I would not share a room if it were left to me alone. Would you not work alongside the one you hated worst, if it would save your friends?"

nɪneɪiv nɑɾəd ɹɪlʌktənli. "bʌt jə stɪl hævən toʊld əs wʌt kaɪndə deɪnʒɝ ðəɹ ɪn. liɑnʒɹɪn sədaɪ."

Nynaeve nodded reluctantly. "But you still haven't told us what kind of danger they're in. Liandrin Sedai."

"ðə deɪnʒɝ kʌmz fɹəm ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl. ðeɪ ɑɹ hʌntəd, əz aɪ ʌndɝstæn ðeɪ wʌns bɪfɔɹ wɝ. ɪf jəl kʌm wɪð mi, səm deɪnʒɝz, ət list, meɪ bi ɪlɪməneɪɾəd. də nɑɾ æsk haʊ, fəɹ aɪ kænɑt tɛl ju, bʌɾ aɪ tɛl jə flætli ɪts soʊ."

"The danger comes from Shayol Ghul. They are hunted, as I understand they once before were. If you will come with me, some dangers, at least, may be eliminated. Do not ask how, for I cannot tell you, but I tell you flatly it is so."

"wi wɪl kʌm, liɑnʒɹɪn sədaɪ," ɛɡwin sɛd.

"We will come, Liandrin Sedai," Egwene said.

"kʌm wɛɹ?" nɪneɪiv sɛd. ɛɡwin ʃɑɾ əɹ ən ɪɡzæspɝeɪɾɪd lʊk.

"Come where?" Nynaeve said. Egwene shot her an exasperated look.

"toʊmən hɛd."

"Toman Head."

ɛɡwinz maʊθ fɛl oʊpən, ən nɪneɪiv mʌɾɝd, "ðɛɹz ə wɔɹ ɑn toʊmən hɛd. dʌz ðɪs deɪnʒɝ əv sʌmθɪŋ tə də wɪð ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz ɑɹmiz?"

Egwene's mouth fell open, and Nynaeve muttered, "There's a war on Toman Head. Does this danger have something to do with Artur Hawkwing's armies?"

"ju bɪliv ɹumɝz, tʃaɪld? bʌɾ ivən ɪf ðeɪ wɝ tʃɹu, ɪz ðəɾ ɪnʌf tə stɑp ju? aɪ θɔt jə kɔl ðiz mɛn fɹɛnz." ə twɪs tə liɑnʒɹɪnz wɝdz sɛd ʃi wəd nɛvɝ də ðə seɪm.

"You believe rumors, child? But even if they were true, is that enough to stop you? I thought you called these men friends." A twist to Liandrin's words said she would never do the same.

"wi wɪl kʌm," ɛɡwin sɛd. nɪneɪiv oʊpən əɹ maʊθ əɡɛn, bʌɾ ɛɡwin wɛn ɹaɪɾ ɑn. "wi wɪl ɡoʊ, nɪneɪiv. ɪf ɹænd nidz əɹ hɛlp - ən mæt, ən pɛɹɪn - wɪv tə ɡɪv ɪt."

"We will come," Egwene said. Nynaeve opened her mouth again, but Egwene went right on. "We will go, Nynaeve. If Rand needs our help - and Mat, and Perrin - we have to give it."

"aɪ noʊ ðæt," nɪneɪiv sɛd, "bʌt wʌɾ aɪ wɑnə noʊ ɪz, waɪ ʌs? wʌt kən wi də ðət mɔɪɹeɪn - əɹ ju, liɑnʒɹɪn - kænɑt?"

"I know that," Nynaeve said, "but what I want to know is, why us? What can we do that Moiraine - or you, Liandrin - cannot?"

ðə waɪt ɡɹu ɪn liɑnʒɹɪnz tʃiks - ɛɡwin ɹilaɪz nɪneɪiv hæd fɝɡɑɾən ði ɑnɝɪfɪk ɪn ədʒɹɛsɪŋ əɹ - bʌt wʌt ʃi sɛd wɑz, "ju tu kʌm fɹəm ðɛɹ vɪlədʒ. ɪn səm weɪ aɪ də nɑɾ ɪntaɪɝli ʌndɝstænd, jə ɑɹ kənɛktəd tə ðɛm. bɪɑn ðæt, aɪ kænɑt seɪ. ən noʊ mɔɹ ə jəɹ fulɪʃ kwɛstʃənz wɪl aɪ ænsɝ. wɪl jə kʌm wɪð mi fəɹ ðɛɹ seɪk?" ʃi pɔz fəɹ ðɛɹ əsɛnt; ə vɪzəbəl tɛnʃən lɛft əɹ wən ðeɪ nɑɾəd. "ɡʊd. jəl mit mi ət ðə nɔɹðɝnmoʊst ɛdʒ ə ði oʊɡiɝ ɡɹoʊv wʌn aʊɝ bɪfɔɹ sʌnsɛt wɪð jəɹ hɔɹsəz ən wʌtɛvɝ jəl nid fəɹ ðə dʒɝni. tɛl noʊ wʌn ə ðɪs."

The white grew in Liandrin's cheeks - Egwene realized Nynaeve had forgotten the honorific in addressing her - but what she said was, "You two come from their village. In some way I do not entirely understand, you are connected to them. Beyond that, I cannot say. And no more of your foolish questions will I answer. Will you come with me for their sake?" She paused for their assent; a visible tension left her when they nodded. "Good. You will meet me at the northernmost edge of the Ogier grove one hour before sunset with your horses and whatever you will need for the journey. Tell no one of this."

"wi ɑɹ nɑt səpoʊz tə liv ðə taʊɝ ɡɹaʊnz wɪθaʊt pɝmɪʃən," nɪneɪiv sɛd sloʊli.

"We are not supposed to leave the Tower grounds without permission," Nynaeve said slowly.

"ju hæv maɪ pɝmɪʃən. tɛl noʊ wʌn. noʊ wʌn əɾ ɔl. ðə blæk ədʒɑ wɔks ðə hɔlz ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ."

"You have my permission. Tell no one. No one at all. The Black Ajah walks the halls of the White Tower."

ɛɡwin ɡæspt, ən hɝɾ ən ɛkoʊd ɡæsp fɹəm nɪneɪiv, bʌt nɪneɪiv ɹəkʌvɝd kwɪkli. "aɪ θɔɾ ɔl ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪnaɪd ði ɛɡzɪstəns ʌv - ʌv ðæt."

Egwene gasped, and heard an echoed gasp from Nynaeve, but Nynaeve recovered quickly. "I thought all Aes Sedai denied the existence of - of that."

liɑnʒɹɪnz maʊθ taɪɾənd ɪndə ə snɪɹ. "mɛni du, bʌt tɑɹmən ɡdən əpɹoʊtʃɪz, ən ðə taɪm livz wən dɪnaɪəlz kən bi meɪd. ðə blæk ədʒɑ, ɪts ði ɑpəzəɾ ʌv ɛvɹiθɪŋ fəɹ wɪtʃ ðə taʊɝ stænz, bʌɾ ɪɾ ɪɡzɪsts, tʃaɪld. ɪts ɛvɹiwɛɹ, ɛni wʊmən kəd bɪlɔŋ tə ɪt, ən ɪt sɝvz ðə dɑɹk wʌn. ɪf jəɹ fɹɛnz ɑɹ pɝsud baɪ ðə ʃædoʊ, dʒju θɪŋk ðə blæk ədʒɑ wɪl liv jə əlaɪv ən fɹi tə hɛlp ðɛm? tɛl noʊ wʌn - noʊ wʌn! - əɹ jə meɪ nɑt lɪv tə ɹitʃ toʊmən hɛd. wʌn aʊɝ bɪfɔɹ sʌnsɛt. də nɑt feɪl mi." wɪð ðæt, ʃi wɑz ɡɔn, ðə dɔɹ kloʊzɪŋ fɝmli bɪhaɪn hɝ.

Liandrin's mouth tightened into a sneer. "Many do, but Tarmon Gai'don approaches, and the time leaves when denials can be made. The Black Ajah, it is the opposite of everything for which the Tower stands, but it exists, child. It is everywhere, any woman could belong to it, and it serves the Dark One. If your friends are pursued by the Shadow, do you think the Black Ajah will leave you alive and free to help them? Tell no one - no one! - or you may not live to reach Toman Head. One hour before sunset. Do not fail me." With that, she was gone, the door closing firmly behind her.

ɛɡwin kəlæpst ɑntu hɝ bɛd wɪð əɹ hænz ɑn əɹ niz. "nɪneɪiv, ʃiz ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ. ʃi kænt noʊ əbaʊt ɹænd. ɪf ʃi dɪd. . . ."

Egwene collapsed onto her bed with her hands on her knees. "Nynaeve, she's Red Ajah. She can't know about Rand. If she did. . . ."

"ʃi kænɑt noʊ," nɪneɪiv əɡɹid. "aɪ wɪʃ aɪ nu waɪ ə ɹɛd wɑntəd tə hɛlp. əɹ waɪ ʃiz wɪlɪŋ tə wɝk wɪð mɔɪɹeɪn. aɪɾ əv swɔɹn niðɝ ə ðɛm wəd ɡɪv ði ʌðɝ wɔɾɝ ɪf ʃi wɝ daɪɪŋ ə θɝst."

"She cannot know," Nynaeve agreed. "I wish I knew why a Red wanted to help. Or why she's willing to work with Moiraine. I'd have sworn neither of them would give the other water if she were dying of thirst."

"ju θɪŋk ʃiz laɪɪŋ?"

"You think she's lying?"

"ʃi ɪz ɛɛs sədaɪ," nɪneɪiv sɛd dʒɹaɪli. "aɪl weɪdʒɝ maɪ bɛst sɪlvɝ pɪn əɡɛnst ə blubɛɹi ðəɾ ɛvɹi wɝd ʃi sɛd wɑz tʃɹu. bʌɾ aɪ wʌndɝ ɪf wi hɝd wʌt wi θɔt wi dɪd."

"She is Aes Sedai," Nynaeve said dryly. "I'll wager my best silver pin against a blueberry that every word she said was true. But I wonder if we heard what we thought we did."

"ðə blæk ədʒɑ." ɛɡwin ʃɪvɝd. "ðɛɹ wɑz noʊ mɪsteɪkɪŋ wʌt ʃi sɛɾ əbaʊt ðæt, ðə laɪt hɛlp ʌs."

"The Black Ajah." Egwene shivered. "There was no mistaking what she said about that, the Light help us."

"noʊ mɪsteɪkɪŋ," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "ænd ʃiz fɔɹstɑld əs æskɪŋ ɛniwʌn fəɹ ædvaɪs, kəz æftɝ ðæt, hu kən wi tʃɹʌst? ðə laɪt hɛlp əs ɪndid."

"No mistaking," Nynaeve said. "And she's forestalled us asking anyone for advice, because after that, who can we trust? The Light help us indeed."

mɪn ən ɪleɪn keɪm bʌsəlɪŋ ɪn, slæmɪŋ ðə dɔɹ bɪhaɪn ðɛm. "ɑɹ jə ɹɪli ɡoʊɪŋ?" mɪn æskt, ən ɪleɪn dʒɛstʃɝd təwɔɹd ðə taɪni hoʊl ɪn ðə wɔl əbʌv ɛɡwinz bɛd, seɪɪŋ, "wi lɪsən fɹəm maɪ ɹum. wi hɝɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ."

Min and Elayne came bustling in, slamming the door behind them. "Are you really going?" Min asked, and Elayne gestured toward the tiny hole in the wall above Egwene's bed, saying, "We listened from my room. We heard everything."

ɛɡwin ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ɡlænsɪz wɪð nɪneɪiv, wʌndɝɪŋ haʊ mʌtʃ ðeɪ hæɾ oʊvɝhɝd, ən sɔ ðə seɪm kənsɝn ɑn nɪneɪivz feɪs. ɪf ðeɪ mænədʒ tə saɪfɝ aʊɾ əbaʊt ɹænd. . . .

Egwene exchanged glances with Nynaeve, wondering how much they had overheard, and saw the same concern on Nynaeve's face. If they manage to cipher out about Rand. . . .

"ju hæv tə kip ðɪs tə jʊɹsɛlvz," nɪneɪiv kɑʃən ðɛm. "aɪ səpoʊz liɑnʒɹɪn əz ɝeɪnʒd pɝmɪʃən fɹəm ʃɛɹiəm fəɹ əs tə ɡoʊ, bʌɾ ivən ɪf ʃi hæzənt, ivən ɪf ðeɪ stɑɹt sɝtʃɪŋ ðə taʊɝ fɹəm tɑp tə bɑɾəm fəɹ əs təmɑɹoʊ, jə mʌsnt seɪ ə wɝd."

"You have to keep this to yourselves," Nynaeve cautioned them. "I suppose Liandrin has arranged permission from Sheriam for us to go, but even if she hasn't, even if they start searching the Tower from top to bottom for us tomorrow, you mustn't say a word."

"kip ɪt tə maɪsɛlf?" mɪn sɛd. "noʊ fɪɹ ɑn ðæt. aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ wɪð ju. ɔl aɪ də ɔl deɪ ɪz tʃɹaɪ tə ɪkspleɪn tə wʌn bɹaʊn sɪstɝ əɹ ənʌðɝ sʌmθɪŋ aɪ doʊn ʌndɝstæn maɪsɛlf. aɪ kæn ivən ɡoʊ fəɹ ə wɔk wɪθaʊt ði æmɪɝlɪn hɝsɛlf pɑpɪŋ aʊɾ ən æskɪŋ mi tə ɹid huɛvɝ wi si. wən ðət wʊmən æsks jə tə də sʌmθɪŋ, ðəɹ dʌzn sim tə bi ɛni weɪ aʊɾ ʌv ɪt. aɪ mʌst əv ɹɛd hæf ðə waɪt taʊɝ fəɹ hɝ, bʌt ʃi ɔlweɪz wɑns ənʌðɝ dɛmənstʃɹeɪʃən. ɔl aɪ niɾəd wɑz ən ɪkskjus tə liv, ən ðɪs ɪz ɪt." hɝ feɪs wɔɹ ə lʊk ə dɪtɝməneɪʃən ðəɾ əlaʊd noʊ ɑɹɡjəmənt.

"Keep it to myself?" Min said. "No fear on that. I'm going with you. All I do all day is try to explain to one Brown sister or another something I don't understand myself. I can't even go for a walk without the Amyrlin herself popping out and asking me to read whoever we see. When that woman asks you to do something, there doesn't seem to be any way out of it. I must have read half the White Tower for her, but she always wants another demonstration. All I needed was an excuse to leave, and this is it." Her face wore a look of determination that allowed no argument.

ɛɡwin wʌndɝd waɪ mɪn wɑz soʊ dɪtɝmən tə ɡoʊ wɪð əm ɹæðɝ ðən sɪmpli livɪŋ ɑn əɹ oʊn, bʌt bɪfɔɹ ʃi hæd taɪm tə də mɔɹ ðən wʌndɝ, ɪleɪn sɛd, "aɪ æm ɡoʊɪŋ, tu."

Egwene wondered why Min was so determined to go with them rather than simply leaving on her own, but before she had time to do more than wonder, Elayne said, "I am going, too."

"ɪleɪn," nɪneɪiv sɛd dʒɛnli, "ɛɡwin ən aɪ ɑɹ ðə bɔɪz' kɪθ fɹəm ɛmənz fild. jə ɑɹ ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ʌv ændɝ. ɪf jə dɪsəpɪɹ fɹəm ðə waɪt taʊɝ, waɪ, ɪt - ɪt kəd stɑɹɾ ə wɔɹ."

"Elayne," Nynaeve said gently, "Egwene and I are the boys' kith from Emond's Field. You are the Daughter-Heir of Andor. If you disappear from the White Tower, why, it - it could start a war."

"mʌðɝ wʊdn stɑɹɾ ə wɔɹ wɪð tɑɹ vəlɑn ɪf ðeɪ dʒɹaɪɾ ən sɔltəd mi, wɪtʃ ðeɪ meɪ bi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə du. ɪf jə θɹi kən ɡoʊ ɔf ən əv ən ædvɛntʃɝ, jə nidn θɪŋk aɪm gɑnə steɪ hɪɹ ən wɑʃ dɪʃəz, ən skɹʌb flɔɹz, ən əv səm æksɛptɪd bɪɹeɪɾɪŋ mi kəz aɪ dɪdn meɪk ðə faɪɝ ði ɪɡzækt ʃeɪɾ ə blu ʃi wɑntəd. ɡɔɪn wɪl daɪ fɹəm ɛnvi wən i faɪnz aʊt." ɪleɪn ɡɹɪn ən ɹitʃt oʊvɝ tə tʌɡ pleɪfəli əɾ ɛɡwinz hɛɹ. "bɪsaɪdz, ɪf jə liv ɹænd laɪɪŋ əbaʊt lus, aɪ maɪɾ əv ə tʃæns tə pɪk ɪm ʌp."

"Mother wouldn't start a war with Tar Valon if they dried and salted me, which they may be trying to do. If you three can go off and have an adventure, you needn't think I am going to stay here and wash dishes, and scrub floors, and have some Accepted berating me because I didn't make the fire the exact shade of blue she wanted. Gawyn will die from envy when he finds out." Elayne grinned and reached over to tug playfully at Egwene's hair. "Besides, if you leave Rand lying about loose, I might have a chance to pick him up."

"aɪ doʊn θɪŋk iðɝ ʌv əs ɪz gɑnə hæv hɪm," ɛɡwin sɛd sædli.

"I don't think either of us is going to have him," Egwene said sadly.

"ðɛn wɪl faɪn huɛvɝ i dʌz tʃuz ən meɪk əɹ laɪf mɪzɝəbəl. bʌɾ i kʊdn bi ful ɪnʌf tə tʃuz sʌmwʌn ɛls wən i kəɾ əv wʌn ʌv ʌs. oʊ, pliz smaɪl, ɛɡwin. aɪ noʊ hiz jʊɹz. aɪ dʒʌs fil" - ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ ðə wɝd - "fɹi. aɪv nɛvɝ hæɾ ən ædvɛntʃɝ. əl bɛt wi woʊn iðɝ ʌv əs kɹaɪ aʊɝsɛlvz tə slip ɑn ən ædvɛntʃɝ. ən ɪf wi du, wɪl meɪk ʃʊɹ ðə ɡlimən liv ðət pɑɹɾ aʊt."

"Then we'll find whoever he does choose and make her life miserable. But he couldn't be fool enough to choose someone else when he could have one of us. Oh, please smile, Egwene. I know he's yours. I just feel" - she hesitated, searching for the word - "free. I've never had an adventure. I'll bet we won't either of us cry ourselves to sleep on an adventure. And if we do, we will make sure the gleemen leave that part out."

"ðɪs ɪz fulɪʃnəs," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "wi ɑɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə toʊmən hɛd. juv hɝd ðə nuz, ən ðə ɹumɝz. ɪɾəl bi deɪnʒɝəs. jə mʌst steɪ hɪɹ."

"This is foolishness," Nynaeve said. "We are going to Toman Head. You've heard the news, and the rumors. It will be dangerous. You must stay here."

"aɪ hɝd wʌt liɑnʒɹɪn sədaɪ sɛɾ əbaʊt ðə - ðə blæk ədʒɑ, tu." ɪleɪnz vɔɪs dʒɹɑpt ɔlmoʊs tə ə wɪspɝ ət ðət neɪm. "haʊ seɪf wɪl aɪ bi hɪɹ, ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹ hɪɹ? ɪf mʌðɝ ivən səspɛktəd ðə blæk ədʒɑ ɹɪli ɪɡzɪstəd, ʃi wəd pɪtʃ mi ɪndə ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ə bæɾəl tə ɡɛt mi əweɪ fɹəm ðɛm."

"I heard what Liandrin Sedai said about the - the Black Ajah, too." Elayne's voice dropped almost to a whisper at that name. "How safe will I be here, if they are here? If Mother even suspected the Black Ajah really existed, she would pitch me into the middle of a battle to get me away from them."

"bʌt, ɪleɪn - "

"But, Elayne - "

"ðɛɹ ɪz oʊnli wʌn weɪ fəɹ jə tə stɑp mi kʌmɪŋ. ðəɾ ɪz tə tɛl ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz. wɪl meɪk ə pɹɪɾi pɪktʃɝ, ɔl θɹi ʌv əs laɪn ʌp ɪn əɹ stʌɾi. ɔl fɔɹ ʌv ʌs. aɪ doʊn θɪŋk mɪn wəɾ ɪskeɪp fɹəm sʌmθɪŋ laɪk ðɪs. soʊ sɪns jə ɑɹ nɑt gɑnə tɛl ʃɛɹiəm sədaɪ, aɪm kʌmɪŋ, tu."

"There is only one way for you to stop me coming. That is to tell the Mistress of Novices. We will make a pretty picture, all three of us lined up in her study. All four of us. I don't think Min would escape from something like this. So since you are not going to tell Sheriam Sedai, I am coming, too."

nɪneɪiv θɹu ʌp əɹ hænz. "pɝhæps jə kən seɪ sʌmθɪŋ tə kənvɪns hɝ," ʃi toʊl mɪn.

Nynaeve threw up her hands. "Perhaps you can say something to convince her," she told Min.

mɪn hæd bɪn linɪŋ əɡɛns ðə dɔɹ, skwɪntɪŋ əɾ ɪleɪn, ən naʊ ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "aɪ θɪŋk ʃiz tə kʌm əz mʌtʃ əz ðə ɹɛst ə ju. ðə ɹɛst ʌv ʌs. aɪ kən si ðə deɪnʒɝ ɝaʊn ɔl ə jə mɔɹ klɪɹli, naʊ. nɑt klɪɹli ɪnʌf tə meɪk ɪɾ aʊt, bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk ɪts sʌmθɪŋ tə də wɪð jə dəsaɪɾɪŋ tə ɡoʊ. ðæts waɪ ɪts klɪɹɝ; kəz ɪts mɔɹ sɝɾən."

Min had been leaning against the door, squinting at Elayne, and now she shook her head. "I think she has to come as much as the rest of you. The rest of us. I can see the danger around all of you more clearly, now. Not clearly enough to make it out, but I think it has something to do with you deciding to go. That's why it is clearer; because it is more certain."

"ðæts noʊ ɹizən fəɹ əɹ tə kʌm," nɪneɪiv sɛd, bʌt mɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ əɡɛn.

"That's no reason for her to come," Nynaeve said, but Min shook her head again.

"ʃi ɪz lɪŋk tə - tə ðoʊz bɔɪz əz mʌtʃ əz ju, əɹ ɛɡwin, əɹ mi. ʃiz pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt, nɪneɪiv, wʌtɛvɝ ɪɾ ɪz. pɑɹɾ ə ðə pæɾɝn, aɪ səpoʊz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ wəd seɪ."

"She is linked to - to those boys as much as you, or Egwene, or me. She's part of it, Nynaeve, whatever it is. Part of the Pattern, I suppose an Aes Sedai would say."

ɪleɪn sim teɪkən əbæk, ən ɪntʃɹəstəd, tu. "aɪ æm? wʌt pɑɹt, mɪn?"

Elayne seemed taken aback, and interested, too. "I am? What part, Min?"

"aɪ kæn si ɪt klɪɹli." mɪn lʊkt ət ðə flɔɹ. "səmtaɪmz aɪ wɪʃ aɪ kʊdn ɹid pipəl əɾ ɔl. moʊs pipəl ɑɹən sæɾəsfaɪd wɪð wʌɾ aɪ si ɛniweɪ."

"I can't see it clearly." Min looked at the floor. "Sometimes I wish I couldn't read people at all. Most people aren't satisfied with what I see anyway."

"ɪf wəɹ ɔl ɡoʊɪŋ," nɪneɪiv sɛd, "ðɛn wi hæd bɛs bi əbaʊt meɪkɪŋ plænz." haʊɛvɝ mʌtʃ ʃi maɪɾ ɑɹɡju bɪfɔɹhænd, wʌns ə kɔɹs ʌv ækʃən hæd bɪn dɪsaɪɾɪd, nɪneɪiv ɔlweɪz wɛn ɹaɪt tə ðə pɹæktəkælɪɾiz: wʌt ðeɪ hæd tə teɪk wɪð ðɛm, ən haʊ koʊld ɪt wəd bi baɪ ðə taɪm ðeɪ ɹitʃt toʊmən hɛd, ən haʊ ðeɪ kəd ɡɛt ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz fɹəm ðə steɪbəlz wɪθaʊt biɪŋ stɑpt.

"If we are all going," Nynaeve said, "then we had best be about making plans." However much she might argue beforehand, once a course of action had been decided, Nynaeve always went right to the practicalities: what they had to take with them, and how cold it would be by the time they reached Toman Head, and how they could get their horses from the stables without being stopped.

lɪsnɪŋ tə hɝ, ɛɡwin kəd nɑt hɛlp wʌndɝɪŋ wʌt ðə deɪnʒɝ wɑz ðət mɪn sɔ fəɹ ðɛm, ən wʌt deɪnʒɝ θɹɛɾənd ɹænd. ʃi nu ʌv oʊnli wʌn deɪnʒɝ ðət kəd θɹɛɾən hɪm, ən ɪt meɪɾ əɹ koʊl tə θɪŋk ʌv ɪt. hoʊld ɑn, ɹænd. hoʊld ɑn, jə wʊl-hɛɾəd ɪɾiət. əl hɛlp jə sʌmhaʊ.

Listening to her, Egwene could not help wondering what the danger was that Min saw for them, and what danger threatened Rand. She knew of only one danger that could threaten him, and it made her cold to think of it. Hold on, Rand. Hold on, you wool-headed idiot. I'll help you somehow.


tʃæptɝ θɝɾinaɪn


CHAPTER 39

flaɪt fɹəm ðə waɪt taʊɝ


Flight from the White Tower

ɛɡwin ən ɪleɪn ɪnklaɪn ðɛɹ hɛdz bɹifli tə itʃ ɡɹup ʌv wɪmən ðeɪ pæst əz ðeɪ meɪd ðɛɹ weɪ θɹu ðə taʊɝ. ɪt wɑz ə ɡʊd θɪŋ ðəɹ wɝ soʊ mɛni wɪmən fɹəm aʊtsaɪɾ ɪn ðə taʊɝ tədeɪ, ɛɡwin θɔt, tu mɛni fəɹ itʃ tə hæv ən ɛɛs sədaɪ əɹ ən æksɛptɪd fəɹ ɛskɔɹt. əloʊn əɹ ɪn smɔl ɡɹups, ɡɑɹbd ɹɪtʃli əɹ pʊɹli, ɪn dʒɹɛs fɹəm hæf ə dʌzən dɪfɹən lænz, səm stɪl dʌsti fɹəm ðɛɹ dʒɝni tə tɑɹ vəlɑn, ðeɪ kɛp tə ðɛmsɛlvz ən weɪɾəd ðɛɹ tɝn tə æsk ðɛɹ kwɛstʃənz ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, əɹ pɹizɛn ðɛɹ pətɪʃənz. səm wɪmən - leɪɾiz əɹ mɝtʃəns əɹ mɝtʃəns' waɪvz - hæd fimeɪl sɝvəns wɪð ðɛm. ivən ə fju mɛn hæd kʌm wɪð pətɪʃənz, stændɪŋ baɪ ðɛmsɛlvz, lʊkɪŋ ənʃʊɹ əbaʊt biɪŋ ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ən aɪɪŋ ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls ənizəli.

Egwene and Elayne inclined their heads briefly to each group of women they passed as they made their way through the Tower. It was a good thing there were so many women from outside in the Tower today, Egwene thought, too many for each to have an Aes Sedai or an Accepted for escort. Alone or in small groups, garbed richly or poorly, in dress from half a dozen different lands, some still dusty from their journey to Tar Valon, they kept to themselves and waited their turn to ask their questions of the Aes Sedai, or present their petitions. Some women - ladies or merchants or merchants' wives - had female servants with them. Even a few men had come with petitions, standing by themselves, looking unsure about being in the White Tower, and eyeing everyone else uneasily.

ɪn ðə lɛd, nɪneɪiv kɛpt əɹ aɪz pɝpəsfəli əhɛd, hɝ kloʊk swɝlɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɝ, wɔkɪŋ əz ɪf ʃi nu wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ - wɪtʃ ʃi dɪd, əz lɔŋ əz noʊ wʌn stɑpt əm - ən hæɾ ə pɝfəkt ɹaɪt tə ɡoʊ ðəɹ - wɪtʃ wɑz ə dɪfɹən mæɾɝ ɔltəɡɛðɝ, ʌv kɔɹs. dʒɹɛs naʊ ɪn ðə kloʊðz ðeɪ hæd bɹɔt tə tɑɹ vəlɑn, ðeɪ sɝɾənli dɪd nɑt lʊk laɪk ɹɛzəɾənts ə ðə taʊɝ. itʃ hæd tʃoʊzən əɹ bɛs dʒɹɛs ðət hæɾ ə skɝt dɪvaɪɾəd fəɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ, ən kloʊks ə faɪn wʊl ɹɪtʃ wɪð ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi. əz lɔŋ əz ðeɪ kɛpt əweɪ fɹəm ɔl u maɪt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz əm - ðeɪ hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi dɑdʒ sɛvɹəl u nu ðɛɹ feɪsəz - ɛɡwin θɔt ðeɪ maɪt meɪk ɪt.

In the lead, Nynaeve kept her eyes purposefully ahead, her cloak swirling behind her, walking as if she knew where they were going - which she did, as long as no one stopped them - and had a perfect right to go there - which was a different matter altogether, of course. Dressed now in the clothes they had brought to Tar Valon, they certainly did not look like residents of the Tower. Each had chosen her best dress that had a skirt divided for riding, and cloaks of fine wool rich with embroidery. As long as they kept away from all who might recognize them - they had already dodged several who knew their faces - Egwene thought they might make it.

"ðɪs wəd də bɛɾɝ fəɹ ə tɝn ɪn səm lɔɹdz pɑɹk ðən ə ɹaɪd tə toʊmən hɛd," nɪneɪiv hæd sɛd dʒɹaɪli əz ɛɡwin hɛlpt əɹ wɪð ðə bʌɾənz ʌv ə ɡɹeɪ sɪlk wɪð θɹɛd-ʌv-ɡoʊld wɝk ən pɝl flaʊɝz əkɹɔs ðə bʊzəm ən daʊn ðə slivz, "bʌɾ ɪt meɪ əlaʊ əs tə liv ənnoʊɾɪst."

"This would do better for a turn in some lord's park than a ride to Toman Head," Nynaeve had said dryly as Egwene helped her with the buttons of a gray silk with thread-of-gold work and pearled flowers across the bosom and down the sleeves, "but it may allow us to leave unnoticed."

naʊ ɛɡwin ʃɪftəɾ əɹ kloʊk ən smuðd əɹ oʊn ɡoʊld-ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd, ɡɹin sɪlk dʒɹɛs ən ɡlænst əɾ ɪleɪn, ɪn blu slæʃt wɪð kɹim, hoʊpɪŋ nɪneɪiv hæd bɪn ɹaɪt. soʊ fɑɹ, ɛvɹiwʌn hæd teɪkən əm fəɹ pətɪʃənɝz, noʊbəlz, əɹ ət list wɪmən ʌv wɛlθ, bʌɾ ɪt sim ðət ðeɪ ʃəd stæn aʊt. ʃi wɑz sɝpɹaɪz tə ɹilaɪz waɪ; ʃi fɛlt ənkʌmftəɹbəl ɪn ðə faɪn dʒɹɛs æftɝ wɛɹɪŋ ə nɑvəsəz pleɪn waɪt fəɹ ðə pæs fju mʌnθs.

Now Egwene shifted her cloak and smoothed her own gold-embroidered, green silk dress and glanced at Elayne, in blue slashed with cream, hoping Nynaeve had been right. So far, everyone had taken them for petitioners, nobles, or at least women of wealth, but it seemed that they should stand out. She was surprised to realize why; she felt uncomfortable in the fine dress after wearing a novice's plain white for the past few months.

ə lɪɾəl klʌstɝ ə vɪlədʒ wɪmən ɪn staʊt, dɑɹk wʊlənz dʒɹɑp kɝtsiz əz ðeɪ pæst. ɛɡwin ɡlæns bæk ət mɪn əz sun əz ðeɪ wɝ bɪɑnd. mɪn hæd kɛpt əɹ bɹitʃɪz ən bæɡi mænz ʃɝɾ ʌndɝ ə bɔɪz bɹaʊn kloʊk ən koʊt, wɪð ən oʊld, waɪd-bɹɪm hæt pʊl daʊn oʊvɝ əɹ ʃɔɹt hɛɹ. "wʌn ʌv əs əz tə bi ðə sɝvənt," ʃi hæd sɛd, læfɪŋ. "wɪmən dʒɹɛs ðə weɪ jə ɑɹ ɔlweɪz əv ət list wʌn. jəl wɪʃ jə hæd maɪ bɹitʃɪz ɪf wɪv tə ɹʌn." ʃi wɑz bɝɾənd wɪð fɔɹ sɛts ə sæɾəlbæɡz bʌlʒɪŋ wɪð wɔɹm kloʊðz, fəɹ ɪt wəd ʃʊɹli bi wɪntɝ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ ɹɪtɝnd. ðəɹ wɝ ɔlsoʊ pækɪts ə fud pɪlfɝd fɹəm ðə kɪtʃənz, ɪnʌf tə læst əntɪl ðeɪ kəd baɪ mɔɹ.

A little cluster of village women in stout, dark woolens dropped curtsies as they passed. Egwene glanced back at Min as soon as they were beyond. Min had kept her breeches and baggy man's shirt under a boy's brown cloak and coat, with an old, wide-brimmed hat pulled down over her short hair. "One of us has to be the servant," she had said, laughing. "Women dressed the way you are always have at least one. You'll wish you had my breeches if we have to run." She was burdened with four sets of saddlebags bulging with warm clothes, for it would surely be winter before they returned. There were also packets of food pilfered from the kitchens, enough to last until they could buy more.

"ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ aɪ kæn kæɹi səm ə ðoʊz, mɪn?" ɛɡwin æsk sɔfli.

"Are you sure I can't carry some of those, Min?" Egwene asked softly.

"ðeɪɹ dʒʌst ɑkwɝd," mɪn sɛd wɪð ə ɡɹɪn, "nɑt hɛvi." ʃi sim tə θɪŋk ɪt wɑz ɔl ə ɡeɪm, əɹ ɛls wɑz pɹitɛndɪŋ tə θɪŋk soʊ. "æn pipəl wəd bi ʃʊɹ tə wʌndɝ waɪ ə faɪn leɪɾi sətʃ əz jɝsɛlf wɑz kæɹiɪŋ əɹ oʊn sæɾəlbæɡz. jə kən kæɹi jʊɹz - ən maɪn, tu, ɪf jə wɑnt - wʌns wi - " hɝ ɡɹɪn vænɪʃt, ən ʃi wɪspɝd fɪɹsli, "ɛɛs sədaɪ!"

"They're just awkward," Min said with a grin, "not heavy." She seemed to think it was all a game, or else was pretending to think so. "And people would be sure to wonder why a fine lady such as yourself was carrying her own saddlebags. You can carry yours - and mine, too, if you want - once we - " Her grin vanished, and she whispered fiercely, "Aes Sedai!"

ɛɡwin wɪpt əɹ aɪz fɔɹwɝd. ən ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪð lɔŋ, smuð blæk hɛɹ ən eɪdʒd-aɪvɝi skɪn wɑz kʌmɪŋ təwɔɹɾ əm daʊn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ, lɪsnɪŋ tə ə wʊmən wɛɹɪŋ ɹʌf fɑɹm kloʊðz ən ə pætʃt kloʊk. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd nɑt sin əm jɛt, bʌɾ ɛɡwin ɹɛkəɡnaɪz hɝ; tɑkimə, ʌv ðə bɹaʊn ədʒɑ, hu tɔt ðə hɪstɝi ʌv ðə waɪt taʊɝ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən u kəd ɹɛkəɡnaɪz wʌn ə hɝ pjupəlz əɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz.

Egwene whipped her eyes forward. An Aes Sedai with long, smooth black hair and aged-ivory skin was coming toward them down the corridor, listening to a woman wearing rough farm clothes and a patched cloak. The Aes Sedai had not seen them yet, but Egwene recognized her; Takima, of the Brown Ajah, who taught the history of the White Tower and Aes Sedai, and who could recognize one of her pupils at a hundred paces.

nɪneɪiv tɝn daʊn ə saɪd hɔl wɪθaʊt bɹeɪkɪŋ stʃɹaɪd, bʌt ðəɹ wʌn ə ði æksɛptɪd, ə læŋki wʊmən wɪð ə pɝmənən fɹaʊn, hɝid pæst əm hɔlɪŋ ə ɹɛd-feɪs nɑvəs baɪ ði ɪɹ.

Nynaeve turned down a side hall without breaking stride, but there one of the Accepted, a lanky woman with a permanent frown, hurried past them hauling a red-faced novice by the ear.

ɛɡwin hæd tə swɑloʊ bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd spik. "ðæt wɑz aɪɹɛlə, ən ɛls. dɪd ðeɪ noʊɾəs ʌs?" ʃi kəd nɑt meɪk hɝsɛlf lʊk bæk tə si.

Egwene had to swallow before she could speak. "That was Irella, and Else. Did they notice us?" She could not make herself look back to see.

"noʊ," mɪn sɛɾ æftɝ ə moʊmənt. "ɔl ðeɪ sɔ wɑz əɹ kloʊðz." ɛɡwin lɛɾ aʊɾ ə lɔŋ, ɹɪliv bɹɛθ, ən hɝd wʌn fɹəm nɪneɪiv, tu.

"No," Min said after a moment. "All they saw was our clothes." Egwene let out a long, relieved breath, and heard one from Nynaeve, too.

"maɪ hɑɹt meɪ bɝs bɪfɔɹ wi ɹitʃ ðə steɪbəlz," ɪleɪn mɝmɝd. "ɪz ðɪs wʌɾ ən ædvɛntʃɝ ɪz laɪk ɔl ðə taɪm, ɛɡwin? jəɹ hɑɹɾ ɪn jəɹ maʊθ, ən jəɹ stʌmək ɪn jəɹ fit?"

"My heart may burst before we reach the stables," Elayne murmured. "Is this what an adventure is like all the time, Egwene? Your heart in your mouth, and your stomach in your feet?"

"aɪ səpoʊz ɪɾ ɪz," ɛɡwin sɛd sloʊli. ʃi faʊn ɪt hɑɹd tə θɪŋk ðət ðəɹ hæd bɪn ə taɪm wən ʃi hæd bɪn iɡɝ tə hæv ən ædvɛntʃɝ, tə də sʌmθɪŋ deɪnʒɝəs ən ɪksaɪɾɪŋ laɪk ðə pipəl ɪn stɔɹiz. naʊ ʃi θɔt ði ɪksaɪɾɪŋ pɑɹt wɑz wʌt jə ɹɪmɛmbɝd wən jə lʊk bæk, ən ðə stɔɹiz lɛft aʊɾ ə ɡʊd dil ʌv ənplɛzəntnəs. ʃi toʊld ɪleɪn əz mʌtʃ.

"I suppose it is," Egwene said slowly. She found it hard to think that there had been a time when she had been eager to have an adventure, to do something dangerous and exciting like the people in stories. Now she thought the exciting part was what you remembered when you looked back, and the stories left out a good deal of unpleasantness. She told Elayne as much.

"stɪl," ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ sɛd fɝmli, "aɪ hæv nɛvɝ hæɾ ɛni ɹil ɪksaɪtmən bɪfɔɹ, ən nɛvɝ laɪkli tə əz lɔŋ əz mʌðɝ əz ɛni seɪ ɪn ɪt, wɪtʃ ʃɪl əntɪl aɪ teɪk ðə θɹoʊn maɪsɛlf."

"Still," the Daughter-Heir said firmly, "I have never had any real excitement before, and never likely to as long as Mother has any say in it, which she will until I take the throne myself."

"ju tu bi kwaɪət," nɪneɪiv sɛd. ðeɪ wɝ əloʊn ɪn ðə hɔl fəɹ ə tʃeɪnʒ, wɪð noʊ wʌn ɪn saɪɾ ɪn iðɝ dɝɛkʃən. ʃi pɔɪntəd tə ə nɛɹoʊ flaɪɾ ə stɛɹz ɡoʊɪŋ daʊn. "ðæt ʃəd bi wʌt wi wɑnt. ɪf aɪ hævənt ɡɑɾən tɝn ɝaʊn kəmplitli, wɪð ɔl ðə twɪsts ən tɝnz wiv meɪd."
