"You two be quiet," Nynaeve said. They were alone in the hall for a change, with no one in sight in either direction. She pointed to a narrow flight of stairs going down. "That should be what we want. If I haven't gotten turned around completely, with all the twists and turns we've made."

ʃi tʊk ðə stɛɹz əz ɪf ʃi wɝ sɝɾən ɛniweɪ, ən ði ʌðɝz fɑloʊd. ʃʊɹli ɪnʌf, ðə smɔl dɔɹ ət ðə bɑɾəm lɛɾ aʊɾ ɪndə ðə dʌsti jɑɹɾ ə ðə saʊθ steɪbəl, wɛɹ nɑvəsɪz' hɔɹsəz wɝ kɛpt, fəɹ ðoʊz u hæd ðɛm, əntɪl ðeɪ hæd niɾ ə maʊns əɡɛn, wɪtʃ wɑz dʒɛnɝəli nɑɾ əntɪl ðeɪ bɪkeɪm æksɛptɪɾ əɹ wɝ sɛn hoʊm. ðə ɡlimɪŋ bʌlk ə ðə taʊɝ ɪtsɛlf ɹoʊz bɪhaɪn ðɛm; ðə taʊɝ ɡɹaʊnz spɹɛɾ oʊvɝ ə ɡʊd mɛni haɪdz ə lænd, wɪð ɪts oʊn wɔlz haɪɝ ðən səm sɪɾi wɔlz.

She took the stairs as if she were certain anyway, and the others followed. Surely enough, the small door at the bottom let out into the dusty yard of the South Stable, where novices' horses were kept, for those who had them, until they had need of mounts again, which was generally not until they became Accepted or were sent home. The gleaming bulk of the Tower itself rose behind them; the Tower grounds spread over a good many hides of land, with its own walls higher than some city walls.

nɪneɪiv stʃɹoʊɾ ɪndə ðə steɪbəl əz ɪf ʃi oʊn ɪt. ɪt hæɾ ə klin smɛl ə heɪ ən hɔɹs, ən tu lɔŋ ɹoʊz ə stɔlz ɹæn bæk ɪndə ʃædoʊz bɑɹd wɪð laɪt fɹəm ðə vɛns əbʌv. fəɹ ə wʌndɝ, ʃæɡi bɛlə ən nɪneɪivz ɡɹeɪ mɛɹ stʊɾ ɪn stɔlz nɪɹ ðə dɔɹz. bɛlə pʊɾ əɹ noʊz oʊvɝ ðə stɔl dɔɹ ən wɪkɝd sɔfli tə ɛɡwin. ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli wʌn ɡɹum ɪn ɛvəɾəns, ə plɛzənt-lʊkɪŋ fɛloʊ wɪð ɡɹeɪ ɪn ɪz bɪɹd, tʃuɪŋ ə stʃɹɔ.

Nynaeve strode into the stable as if she owned it. It had a clean smell of hay and horse, and two long rows of stalls ran back into shadows barred with light from the vents above. For a wonder, shaggy Bela and Nynaeve's gray mare stood in stalls near the doors. Bela put her nose over the stall door and whickered softly to Egwene. There was only one groom in evidence, a pleasant-looking fellow with gray in his beard, chewing a straw.

"wi wɪl əv əɹ hɔɹsəz sæɾəld," nɪneɪiv toʊld ɪm ɪn əɹ moʊs kəmændɪŋ toʊn. "ðoʊz tu. mɪn, faɪn jəɹ hɔɹs ən ɪleɪnz." mɪn dʒɹɑp ðə sæɾəlbæɡz ən dʒɹu ɪleɪn dipɝ ɪndə ðə steɪbəlz.

"We will have our horses saddled," Nynaeve told him in her most commanding tone. "Those two. Min, find your horse and Elayne's." Min dropped the saddlebags and drew Elayne deeper into the stables.

ðə steɪbəlmən fɹaʊn æftɝ əm ən sloʊli tʊk ðə stʃɹɔ fɹəm ɪz maʊθ. "ðɛɹ mʌs bi səm mɪsteɪk, maɪ leɪɾi. ðoʊz ænəməlz - "

The stableman frowned after them and slowly took the straw from his mouth. "There must be some mistake, my Lady. Those animals - "

" - ɑɹ aʊɝz," nɪneɪiv sɛd fɝmli, foʊldɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz soʊ ðət ðə sɝpən ɹɪŋ wɑz ɑbviəs. "ju wɪl sæɾəl əm naʊ."

" - are ours," Nynaeve said firmly, folding her arms so that the Serpent ring was obvious. "You will saddle them now."

ɛɡwin hɛld əɹ bɹɛθ; ɪt wɑz ə læst-dɪtʃ plæn, ðət nɪneɪiv wəd tʃɹaɪ tə pæs əz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪf ðeɪ hæd dɪfəkəltiz wɪð ɛniwʌn u maɪɾ æktʃəli  æksɛpt əɹ əz wʌn. noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ əɹ æksɛptɪd wʊd, ʌv kɔɹs, ən pɹɑbli nɑɾ ivən ə nɑvəs, bʌɾ ə steɪbəlmən. . . .

Egwene held her breath; it was a last-ditch plan, that Nynaeve would try to pass as an Aes Sedai if they had difficulties with anyone who might actually accept her as one. No Aes Sedai or Accepted would, of course, and probably not even a novice, but a stableman. . . .

ðə mæn blɪŋkt ət nɪneɪivz ɹɪŋ, ðən ət hɝ. "aɪ wɑz toʊl tu," hi sɛɾ ət læst, saʊndɪŋ ʌnɪmpɹɛst. "wʌn ə ði æksɛptɪɾ ən ə nɑvəs. wɑznt nʌθɪŋ sɛɾ əbaʊt fɔɹ ə ju."

The man blinked at Nynaeve's ring, then at her. "I was told two," he said at last, sounding unimpressed. "One of the Accepted and a novice. Wasn't nothing said about four of you."

ɛɡwin fɛlt laɪk læfɪŋ. ʌv kɔɹs liɑnʒɹɪn wəd nɑɾ əv bɪlivd əm eɪbəl tə ɡɛt ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz baɪ ðɛmsɛlvz.

Egwene felt like laughing. Of course Liandrin would not have believed them able to get their horses by themselves.

nɪneɪiv lʊk dɪsəpɔɪntɪd, ən əɹ vɔɪs ʃɑɹpənd. "ju tʃɹɑt ðoʊz hɔɹsəz aʊɾ ən sæɾəl ðɛm, əɹ jəl əv niɾ ə liɑnʒɹɪnz hilɪŋ, ɪf ʃɪl ɡɪv ɪt tə ju."

Nynaeve looked disappointed, and her voice sharpened. "You trot those horses out and saddle them, or you'll have need of Liandrin's Healing, if she will give it to you."

ðə ɡɹum maʊð liɑnʒɹɪnz neɪm, bʌt wʌn lʊk ət nɪneɪivz feɪs ən i sɔ tə ðə hɔɹsəz wɪð noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə mʌɾɝ əɹ tu, nɑt laʊɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ ɛni bʌt hɪmsɛlf tə hɪɹ. mɪn ən ɪleɪn keɪm bæk wɪð ðɛɹ oʊn maʊns dʒʌst əz i fɪnɪʃt taɪɾənɪŋ ðə sɛkənd ɡɝθ. mɪnz wɑz ə tɔl dʌst-kʌlɝd ɡɛldɪŋ, ɪleɪnz ə beɪ mɛɹ wɪð ən ɑɹtʃt nɛk.

The groom mouthed Liandrin's name, but one look at Nynaeve's face and he saw to the horses with no more than a mutter or two, not loud enough for any but himself to hear. Min and Elayne came back with their own mounts just as he finished tightening the second girth. Min's was a tall dust-colored gelding, Elayne's a bay mare with an arched neck.

wən ðeɪ wɝ maʊntəd, nɪneɪiv ədʒɹɛs hɝsɛlf tə ðə steɪbəlmən əɡɛn. "noʊ daʊt jə wɝ toʊl tə kip ðɪs kwaɪət, ən ðət hæzən tʃeɪnʒd wɛðɝ wəɹ tu əɹ tu hʌnʒɹəd. ɪf jə θɪŋk ɪt hæz, θɪŋk əbaʊt wʌt liɑnʒɹɪn wɪl də ɪf jə tɔk wʌt jə wɝ toʊl tə kip kwaɪət."

When they were mounted, Nynaeve addressed herself to the stableman again. "No doubt you were told to keep this quiet, and that hasn't changed whether we are two or two hundred. If you think it has, think about what Liandrin will do if you talk what you were told to keep quiet."

əz ðeɪ wɝ ɹaɪɾɪŋ aʊt, ɪleɪn tɔst ɪm ə kɔɪn ən mɝmɝd, "fɔɹ jəɹ tʃɹʌbəl, ɡʊdmən. juv dʌn wɛl." aʊtsaɪd, ʃi kɑɾ ɛɡwinz aɪ ən smaɪld. "mʌðɝ sɛz ə stɪk ən hʌni ɔlweɪz wɝk bɛɾɝ ðən ə stɪk əloʊn."

As they were riding out, Elayne tossed him a coin and murmured, "For your trouble, goodman. You have done well." Outside, she caught Egwene's eye and smiled. "Mother says a stick and honey always work better than a stick alone."

"aɪ hoʊp wi doʊnt niɾ iðɝ wɪð ðə ɡɑɹdz," ɛɡwin sɛd. "aɪ hoʊp liɑnʒɹɪn spoʊk tə ðɛm, tu."

"I hope we don't need either with the guards," Egwene said. "I hope Liandrin spoke to them, too."

ət tɑɹləmənz ɡeɪt, ðoʊ, pɪɹsɪŋ ðə tɔl saʊθ wɔl ə ðə taʊɝ ɡɹaʊnz, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ tɛlɪŋ ɪf ɛniwʌn hæd spoʊkən tə ðə ɡɑɹdz əɹ nɑt. ðeɪ weɪv ðə fɔɹ wɪmən θɹu wɪð noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə ɡlæns ən ə kɝsɝi baʊ. ɡɑɹdz wɝ mɛn tə kip aʊt ðoʊz u wɝ deɪnʒɝəs; əpɛɹənli ðiz hæd noʊ ɔɹɾɝz əbaʊt kipɪŋ ɛniwʌn ɪn.

At Tarlomen's Gate, though, piercing the tall south wall of the Tower grounds, there was no telling if anyone had spoken to the guards or not. They waved the four women through with no more than a glance and a cursory bow. Guards were meant to keep out those who were dangerous; apparently these had no orders about keeping anyone in.

ə kul ɹɪvɝ bɹiz ɡeɪv əm ən ɪkskjus tə pʊl ʌp ðə hʊdz ə ðɛɹ kloʊks əz ðeɪ ɹoʊd sloʊli θɹu ðə stʃɹits ə ðə sɪɾi. ðə ɹɪŋ ə ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz' hʊvz ɑn ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz wɑz lɔst ɪn ðə mɝmɝ ə ðə kɹaʊdz fɪlɪŋ ðə stʃɹits ən ðə mjuzɪk ðət keɪm fɹəm səm ə ðə bɪldɪŋz ðeɪ pæst. pipəl dʒɹɛst ɪn ɡɑɹməns fɹəm ɛvɹi lænd, fɹəm ðə dɑɹk ən sɑmbɝ moʊɾ ə kɛɹhin tə ðə bɹaɪt, bɹɪljən kʌlɝz ə ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ pipəl, ən ɛvɹi staɪl ɪn bɪtwin, splɪɾ ɝaʊn ðə hɔɹswɪmən laɪk ə ɹɪvɝ ɝaʊn ə ɹɑk, bʌt ðeɪ stɪl kəd nɑt muv ət mɔɹ ðən ə sloʊ wɔk.

A cool river breeze gave them an excuse to pull up the hoods of their cloaks as they rode slowly through the streets of the city. The ring of their horses' hooves on the paving stones was lost in the murmur of the crowds filling the streets and the music that came from some of the buildings they passed. People dressed in garments from every land, from the dark and somber mode of Cairhien to the bright, brilliant colors of the Traveling People, and every style in between, split around the horsewomen like a river around a rock, but they still could not move at more than a slow walk.

ɛɡwin ɡeɪv noʊ ətɛnʃən tə ðə fæbjələs taʊɝz wɪð ðɛɹ skaɪ-bɔɹn bɹɪdʒəz əɹ ðə bɪldɪŋz ðət lʊk mɔɹ laɪk bɹeɪkɪŋ weɪvz, əɹ wɪnd-skʌlptɪd klɪfs, əɹ fænsɪfəl ʃɛlz, ðən ɛniθɪŋ meɪd fɹəm stoʊn. ɛɛs sədaɪ ɔfən wɛn ɪndə ðə sɪɾi, ən ɪn ðət kɹaʊd ðeɪ kəd kʌm feɪs-tə-feɪs wɪð wʌn bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ nu ɪt. æftɝ ə taɪm ʃi ɹilaɪz ði ʌðɝ wɪmən wɝ kipɪŋ əz kloʊz ə wɑtʃ əz ʃi, bʌt ʃi stɪl fɛl mɔɹ ðən ə ɡlɪmɝ ə ɹɪlif wən ði oʊɡiɝ ɡɹoʊv keɪm ɪndə vju.

Egwene gave no attention to the fabulous towers with their sky-borne bridges or the buildings that looked more like breaking waves, or wind-sculpted cliffs, or fanciful shells, than anything made from stone. Aes Sedai often went into the city, and in that crowd they could come face-to-face with one before they knew it. After a time she realized the other women were keeping as close a watch as she, but she still felt more than a glimmer of relief when the Ogier grove came into view.

ðə ɡɹeɪt tʃɹiz wɝ naʊ vɪzəbəl bɪɑn ðə ɹuftɑps, ðɛɹ spɹɛɾɪŋ tɑps ə hʌnʒɹəd spænz ən mɔɹ ɪn ði ɛɹ. taʊɝɪŋ oʊks ən ɛlmz, lɛðɝlifs ən fɹz, wɝ dwɔɹf bɪniθ ðɛm. ə wɔl ə sɔɹts ɛnkʌmpəs ðə ɡɹoʊv, wɪtʃ wɑz ə ɡʊd tu maɪlz əkɹɔs, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz oʊnli ən ɛnləs sɪɹiz ə spaɪɹəlɪŋ stoʊn ɑɹtʃəz, itʃ faɪv spænz haɪ ən twaɪs əz waɪd. baɪ ði aʊɾɝ saɪɾ ə ðə wɔl, kæɹɪdʒɪz, kɑɹts, ən pipəl bʌsəld əlɔŋ ə stʃɹit, waɪl ɪnsaɪd leɪ ə wɪldɝnəs ə sɔɹts. ðə ɡɹoʊv hæd niðɝ ðə teɪm lʊk ʌv ə pɑɹk nɔɹ ðə kəmplit hæfəzɝdnəs ə ðə fɔɹəs dɛpθs. ɹæðɝ, ɪt sim tə bi ði aɪdil ə neɪtʃɝ, əz ɪf ðɪs wɝ ðə pɝfəkt wʊdz, ðə moʊs bjuɾəfəl fɔɹəs ðət kəd bi. səm ə ðə livz hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bɪɡʌn tə tɝn, ən ivən ðə smɔl swɑðz ʌv ɔɹənʒ ən jɛloʊ ən ɹɛɾ əmʌŋ ðə ɡɹin sim tə ɛɡwin tə bi ɪɡzækli ðə weɪ ɔɾəm foʊlɪdʒ ʃəd lʊk.

The Great Trees were now visible beyond the rooftops, their spreading tops a hundred spans and more in the air. Towering oaks and elms, leatherleafs and firs, were dwarfed beneath them. A wall of sorts encompassed the grove, which was a good two miles across, but it was only an endless series of spiraling stone arches, each five spans high and twice as wide. By the outer side of the wall, carriages, carts, and people bustled along a street, while inside lay a wilderness of sorts. The grove had neither the tame look of a park nor the complete haphazardness of the forest depths. Rather, it seemed to be the ideal of nature, as if this were the perfect woods, the most beautiful forest that could be. Some of the leaves had already begun to turn, and even the small swathes of orange and yellow and red among the green seemed to Egwene to be exactly the way autumn foliage should look.

ə fju pipəl stʃɹoʊl dʒʌst ɪnsaɪd ði oʊpən ɑɹtʃəz, ən noʊ wʌn lʊk twaɪs wən ðə fɔɹ wɪmən ɹoʊɾ ɪn ʌndɝ ðə tʃɹiz. ðə sɪɾi wɑz kwɪkli lɔs tə vju, ivən ðə saʊnz ʌv ɪt sɔfənd, ðən blɑkt, baɪ ðə ɡɹoʊv. ɪn ðə speɪs ə tɛn stʃɹaɪdz ðeɪ sim tə bi maɪlz fɹəm ðə nɪɹəs taʊn.

A few people strolled just inside the open arches, and no one looked twice when the four women rode in under the trees. The city was quickly lost to view, even the sounds of it softened, then blocked, by the grove. In the space of ten strides they seemed to be miles from the nearest town.

"ðə nɔɹθ ɛdʒ ə ðə ɡɹoʊv, ʃi sɛd," nɪneɪiv mʌɾɝd, piɹɪŋ ɝaʊnd. "ðɛɹ ɪzən ɛni pɔɪn ʌv ɪt fɝðɝ nɔɹθ ðən - " ʃi kʌɾ ɔf əz tu hɔɹsəz bɝs fɹəm ə kɑps ə blæk ɛldɝ, ə dɑɹk, ɡlɔsi mɛɹ wɪð ə ɹaɪɾɝ ən ə laɪtli leɪɾən pæk hɔɹs.

"The north edge of the grove, she said," Nynaeve muttered, peering around. "There isn't any point of it further north than - " She cut off as two horses burst from a copse of black elder, a dark, glossy mare with a rider and a lightly laden pack horse.

ðə dɑɹk mɛɹ ɹɪɹd, pɔɪŋ ði ɛɹ, əz liɑnʒɹɪn ɹeɪn əɹ hɑɹʃli. ði ɛɛs sədaɪz feɪs wɔɹ fjʊɹi laɪk ə mæsk. "aɪ toʊl jə nɑt tə tɛl ɛniwʌn ə ðɪs! nɑɾ ɛniwʌn!" ɛɡwin noʊɾəst poʊl-læntɝnz ɑn ðə pæk hɔɹs, ən θɔɾ ɪɾ ɑd.

The dark mare reared, pawing the air, as Liandrin reined her harshly. The Aes Sedai's face wore fury like a mask. "I told you not to tell anyone of this! Not anyone!" Egwene noticed pole-lanterns on the pack horse, and thought it odd.

"ðiz ɑɹ fɹɛnz," nɪneɪiv bɪɡæn, hɝ bæk stɪfənɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪleɪn bɹoʊk ɪn ɑn hɝ.

"These are friends," Nynaeve began, her back stiffening, but Elayne broke in on her.

"fɝɡɪv ʌs, liɑnʒɹɪn sədaɪ. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt tɛl ʌs; wi oʊvɝhɝd. wi dɪd nɑt min tə lɪsən tə ɛniθɪŋ wi ʃəd nɑt hæv, bʌt wi dɪɾ oʊvɝhɪɹ. ən wi wɑnə hɛlp ɹænd ælθɹ, tu. ən ði ʌðɝ bɔɪz, ʌv kɔɹs," ʃi æɾəd kwɪkli.

"Forgive us, Liandrin Sedai. They did not tell us; we overheard. We did not mean to listen to anything we should not have, but we did overhear. And we want to help Rand al'Thor, too. And the other boys, of course," she added quickly.

liɑnʒɹɪn pɪɹɾ əɾ ɪleɪn ən mɪn. ðə leɪɾ æftɝnun sʌnlaɪt, slæntɪŋ θɹu ðə bɹæntʃəz, ʃæɾoʊd ðɛɹ feɪsəz bɪniθ ðə hʊdz ə ðɛɹ kloʊks. "soʊ," ʃi sɛd faɪnəli, stɪl wɑtʃɪŋ ðoʊz tu. "aɪ hæd meɪɾ ɝeɪnʒmənts fəɹ jə tə bi teɪkən kɛɹ ʌv, bʌɾ əz jə ɑɹ hɪɹ, jə ɑɹ hɪɹ. fɔɹ kən meɪk ðɪs dʒɝni əz wɛl əz tu."

Liandrin peered at Elayne and Min. The late afternoon sunlight, slanting through the branches, shadowed their faces beneath the hoods of their cloaks. "So," she said finally, still watching those two. "I had made arrangements for you to be taken care of, but as you are here, you are here. Four can make this journey as well as two."

"teɪkən kɛɹ ʌv, liɑnʒɹɪn sədaɪ?" ɪleɪn sɛd. "aɪ də nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd."

"Taken care of, Liandrin Sedai?" Elayne said. "I do not understand."

"tʃaɪld, jə ən ðəɾ ʌðɝ ɑɹ noʊn əz fɹɛnz ə ðiz tu. dʒju nɑt θɪŋk ðəɹ ɑɹ ðoʊz u wəd kwɛstʃən jə wən ðeɪ ɑɹ faʊn tə bi ɡɔn? dʒju bɪliv ðə blæk ədʒɑ wəd bi dʒɛntəl wɪð jə dʒʌs kəz jə ɑɹ ɛɹ tə ə θɹoʊn? hæd jə ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, jə maɪt nɑɾ əv lɪv ðə naɪt." ðət saɪlənst əm ɔl fəɹ ə moʊmənt, bʌt liɑnʒɹɪn wild əɹ hɔɹs ən kɔld, "fɑloʊ mi!"

"Child, you and that other are known as friends of these two. Do you not think there are those who would question you when they are found to be gone? Do you believe the Black Ajah would be gentle with you just because you are heir to a throne? Had you remained in the White Tower, you might not have lived the night." That silenced them all for a moment, but Liandrin wheeled her horse and called, "Follow me!"

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ lɛɾ əm dipɝ ɪndə ðə ɡɹoʊv, əntɪl ðeɪ keɪm tə ə tɔl fɛns ə staʊɾ aɪɝnwɝk tɑpt wɪð ə hɛdʒ ə ɹeɪzɝ-ʃɑɹp spaɪks. kɝvɪŋ slaɪtli, əz ɪf ɪɾ ɛnkloʊzd ə lɑɹdʒ ɛɹiə, ðə fɛns ɹæn aʊɾ ə saɪɾ əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz tə lɛft ən ɹaɪt. ðəɹ wɑz ə ɡeɪɾ ɪn ðə fɛns, sɪkjʊɹd wɪð ə bɪɡ lɑk. liɑnʒɹɪn ənfæsən ðɪs wɪð ə lɑɹdʒ ki ʃi pɹədus fɹəm əɹ kloʊk, moʊʃən əm θɹu, ðən ɹilɑkt ɪt bɪhaɪn əm ən ɹoʊɾ ɑn əhɛɾ ɪmiɾiətli. ə skwɝəl tʃɪɾɝd əɾ əm fɹəm ə bɹæntʃ oʊvɝhɛd, ən fɹəm sʌmwɛɹ keɪm ðə ʃɑɹp dʒɹʌmɪŋ ʌv ə wʊdpɛkɝ.

The Aes Sedai led them deeper into the grove, until they came to a tall fence of stout ironwork topped with a hedge of razor-sharp spikes. Curving slightly, as if it enclosed a large area, the fence ran out of sight among the trees to left and right. There was a gate in the fence, secured with a big lock. Liandrin unfastened this with a large key she produced from her cloak, motioned them through, then relocked it behind them and rode on ahead immediately. A squirrel chittered at them from a branch overhead, and from somewhere came the sharp drumming of a woodpecker.

"wɛɹ ɑɹ wi ɡoʊɪŋ?" nɪneɪiv dɪmændəd. liɑnʒɹɪn dɪd nɑɾ ænsɝ, ən nɪneɪiv lʊkt æŋɡɹəli ət ði ʌðɝz. "waɪ ɑɹ wi dʒʌst ɹaɪɾɪŋ dipɝ ɪndə ðiz wʊdz? wɪv tə kɹɔs ə bɹɪdʒ, əɹ ɛls teɪk ʃɪp, ɪf wɝ gɑnə liv tɑɹ vəlɑn, ən ðəɹ ɪzən ɛni bɹɪdʒ əɹ ʃɪp ɪn - "

"Where are we going?" Nynaeve demanded. Liandrin did not answer, and Nynaeve looked angrily at the others. "Why are we just riding deeper into these woods? We have to cross a bridge, or else take ship, if we're going to leave Tar Valon, and there isn't any bridge or ship in - "

"ðɛɹ ɪz ðɪs," liɑnʒɹɪn ənaʊnst. "ðə fɛns, ɪt kips əweɪ ðoʊz u maɪt hɑɹm ðɛmsɛlvz, bʌt wɪv ə nid ðɪs deɪ." wʌt ʃi dʒɛstʃɝd tə wɑz ə tɔl, θɪk slæb ʌv wʌt sim tə bi stoʊn, stændɪŋ ɑn ɛdʒ, wʌn saɪd kɑɹvd ɪntʃɹəkətli ɪn vaɪnz ən livz.

"There is this," Liandrin announced. "The fence, it keeps away those who might harm themselves, but we have a need this day." What she gestured to was a tall, thick slab of what seemed to be stone, standing on edge, one side carved intricately in vines and leaves.

ɛɡwinz θɹoʊt taɪɾənd; sʌɾənli ʃi nu waɪ liɑnʒɹɪn hæd bɹɔt læntɝnz, ən ʃi dɪd nɑt laɪk wʌt ʃi nu. ʃi hɝd nɪneɪiv wɪspɝ, "eɪ weɪɡeɪt." ðeɪ boʊθ ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðə weɪz ɔl tu wɛl.

Egwene's throat tightened; suddenly she knew why Liandrin had brought lanterns, and she did not like what she knew. She heard Nynaeve whisper, "A Waygate." They both remembered the Ways all too well.

"wi dɪɾ ɪt wʌns," ʃi toʊl hɝsɛlf əz mʌtʃ əz nɪneɪiv. "wi kən də ɪɾ əɡɛn." ɪf ɹænd ən ði ʌðɝz niɾ ʌs, wɪv tə hɛlp ðɛm. ðæts ɔl ðəɹ ɪz tə ɪt.

"We did it once," she told herself as much as Nynaeve. "We can do it again." If Rand and the others need us, we have to help them. That's all there is to it.

"ɪz ðət ɹɪli . . . ?" mɪn bɪɡæn ɪn ə tʃoʊk vɔɪs ən kəd nɑt fɪnɪʃ.

"Is that really . . . ?" Min began in a choked voice and could not finish.

"eɪ weɪɡeɪt," ɪleɪn bɹiðd. "aɪ dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ðə weɪz kəd bi juzd ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. ət list, aɪ dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ðɛɹ jus wɑz əlaʊd."

"A Waygate," Elayne breathed. "I did not think the Ways could be used any longer. At least, I did not think their use was allowed."

liɑnʒɹɪn hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi dɪsmaʊntɪɾ ən plʌk ðə tʃɹɛfɔɪl ɑvɛndɪsɔɹə lif aʊɾ ə ðə kɑɹvɪŋ; laɪk tu hjudʒ dɔɹz woʊvən ə lɪvɪŋ vaɪnz, ðə ɡeɪts wɝ swɪŋɪŋ oʊpən, ɹɪvilɪŋ wʌɾ əpɪɹd tə bi ə dʌl, sɪlvɝi mɪɹɝ ðət ɡeɪv ðɛɹ ɹɪflɛkʃənz bæk dɪmli.

Liandrin had already dismounted and plucked the trefoil Avendesora leaf out of the carving; like two huge doors woven of living vines, the gates were swinging open, revealing what appeared to be a dull, silvery mirror that gave their reflections back dimly.

"ju də nɑɾ əv tə kʌm," liɑnʒɹɪn sɛd. "ju kən weɪt hɪɹ fəɹ mi, seɪfli ɛnkloʊz baɪ ðə fɛns əntɪl aɪ kʌm fəɹ ju. əɹ pɝhæps ðə blæk ədʒɑ wɪl faɪn jə bɪfɔɹ ɛniwʌn ɛls." hɝ smaɪl wɑz nɑt plɛzənt. bɪhaɪn hɝ, ðə weɪɡeɪt keɪm oʊpən tə ɪts fʊləst ən stɑpt.

"You do not have to come," Liandrin said. "You can wait here for me, safely enclosed by the fence until I come for you. Or perhaps the Black Ajah will find you before anyone else." Her smile was not pleasant. Behind her, the Waygate came open to its fullest and stopped.

"aɪ dɪd nɑt seɪ aɪ wʊdn kʌm," ɪleɪn sɛd, bʌt ʃi ɡeɪv ðə ʃæɾoʊd wʊdz ə lɪŋɡɝɪŋ lʊk.

"I did not say I wouldn't come," Elayne said, but she gave the shadowed woods a lingering look.

"ɪf wəɹ gɑnə də ðɪs," mɪn sɛd hɔɹsli, "ðɛn lɛts də ɪt." ʃi wɑz stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə weɪɡeɪt, ən ɛɡwin θɔt ʃi hɝɾ əɹ mʌɾɝ, "ðə laɪt bɝn ju, ɹænd ælθɹ."

"If we are going to do this," Min said hoarsely, "then let's do it." She was staring at the Waygate, and Egwene thought she heard her mutter, "The Light burn you, Rand al'Thor."

"aɪ mʌst ɡoʊ læst," liɑnʒɹɪn sɛd. "ɔl ə ju, ɪn. əl fɑloʊ." ʃi wɑz aɪɪŋ ðə wʊdz naʊ, tu, əz ɪf ʃi θɔt sʌmwʌn maɪt bi fɑloʊɪŋ ðɛm. "kwɪkli! kwɪkli!"

"I must go last," Liandrin said. "All of you, in. I will follow." She was eyeing the woods now, too, as if she thought someone might be following them. "Quickly! Quickly!"

ɛɡwin dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt liɑnʒɹɪn ɪkspɛktəd tə si, bʌɾ ɪf ɛniwʌn əɾ ɔl keɪm ðeɪ wəd pɹɑbli stɑp əm fɹəm juzɪŋ ðə weɪɡeɪt. ɹænd, jə wʊl-hɛɾəd ɪɾiət, ʃi θɔt, waɪ kæn jə dʒʌst wʌns ɡɛt jɝsɛlf ɪndə səm kaɪndə tʃɹʌbəl ðət dʌzn fɔɹs mi tə æk laɪk ðə hɛɹoʊən ɪn ə stɔɹi?

Egwene did not know what Liandrin expected to see, but if anyone at all came they would probably stop them from using the Waygate. Rand, you wool-headed idiot, she thought, why can't you just once get yourself into some kind of trouble that doesn't force me to act like the heroine in a story?

ʃi dʌɡ hɝ hilz ɪndə bɛləz flæŋks, ən ðə ʃæɡi mɛɹ, ɹɛstɪv fɹəm tu mʌtʃ taɪm ɪn ə steɪbəl, lɛp fɔɹwɝd.

She dug her heels into Bela's flanks, and the shaggy mare, restive from too much time in a stable, leaped forward.

"sloʊli!" nɪneɪiv ʃaʊɾəd, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz tu leɪt.

"Slowly!" Nynaeve shouted, but it was too late.

ɛɡwin ən bɛlə sɝdʒ təwɔɹd ðɛɹ oʊn dʌl ɹɪflɛkʃənz; tu ʃæɡi hɔɹsəz tʌtʃt noʊzɪz, əpɪɹd tə floʊ ɪndə itʃ ʌðɝ. ðən ɛɡwin wɑz mɝdʒɪŋ ɪndə hɝ oʊn ɪmədʒ wɪð ən aɪsi ʃɑk. taɪm sim tə stʃɹɛtʃ aʊt, əz ɪf ðə koʊl kɹɛpt oʊvɝ əɹ baɪ ðə wɪdθ ʌv wʌn hɛɹ əɾ ə taɪm, ən ɛvɹi hɛɹ tʊk mɪnəts.

Egwene and Bela surged toward their own dull reflections; two shaggy horses touched noses, appeared to flow into each other. Then Egwene was merging into her own image with an icy shock. Time seemed to stretch out, as if the cold crept over her by the width of one hair at a time, and every hair took minutes.

sʌɾənli bɛlə wɑz stʌmbəlɪŋ ɪn pɪtʃ-blæknəs, muvɪŋ soʊ fæs ðə mɛɹ ɔlmoʊs pɪtʃt oʊvɝ ɑn əɹ hɛd. ʃi kɑt hɝsɛlf ən stʊd tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ əz ɛɡwin dɪsmaʊntɪd hɝidli, filɪŋ ðə mɛɹz lɛɡz ɪn ðə dɑɹk tə si ɪf ʃi hæd bɪn hɝt. ʃi wɑz ɔlmoʊst ɡlæɾ ə ðə dɑɹk, tə haɪɾ əɹ kɹɪmzən feɪs. ʃi nu ðət taɪm əz wɛl əz dɪstəns wɝ dɪfɹən ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ʌv ə weɪɡeɪt; ʃi hæd muv bɪfɔɹ θɪŋkɪŋ.

Suddenly Bela was stumbling in pitch-blackness, moving so fast the mare almost pitched over on her head. She caught herself and stood trembling as Egwene dismounted hurriedly, feeling the mare's legs in the dark to see if she had been hurt. She was almost glad of the dark, to hide her crimson face. She knew that time as well as distance were different the other side of a Waygate; she had moved before thinking.

ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli ðə blæknəs ɝaʊn əɹ ɪn ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən, ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə ɹɛktæŋɡəl ə ði oʊpən weɪɡeɪt, laɪk ə wɪndoʊ ʌv smoʊkt ɡlæs wən sin fɹəm ðɪs saɪd. ɪt lɛt noʊ laɪɾ ɪn - ðə blæk sim tə pɹɛs ɹaɪɾ ʌp əɡɛnst ɪt - bʌt θɹu ɪɾ ɛɡwin kəd si ði ʌðɝz, muvɪŋ baɪ ðə sloʊəst ɪŋkɹəməns, laɪk fɪɡjɝz ɪn ə naɪtmɛɹ. nɪneɪiv wɑz ɪnsɪstɪŋ ɑn hændɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə poʊl-læntɝnz ən laɪɾɪŋ ðɛm; liɑnʒɹɪn wɑz æksiɾɪŋ wɪð ə bæd ɡɹeɪs, əpɛɹənli ɪnsɪstɪŋ ɑn spid.

There was only the blackness around her in every direction, except for the rectangle of the open Waygate, like a window of smoked glass when seen from this side. It let no light in - the black seemed to press right up against it - but through it Egwene could see the others, moving by the slowest increments, like figures in a nightmare. Nynaeve was insisting on handing around the pole-lanterns and lighting them; Liandrin was acceding with a bad grace, apparently insisting on speed.

wən nɪneɪiv keɪm ðoʊ ðə weɪɡeɪt - liɾɪŋ əɹ ɡɹeɪ mɛɹ sloʊli, ɛvɝ soʊ sloʊli - ɛɡwin ɔlmoʊst ɹæn tə hʌɡ hɝ, ən ət lis hæf ə hɝ filɪŋ wɑz fəɹ ðə læntɝn nɪneɪiv kæɹid. ðə læntɝn meɪɾ ə smɔlɝ pul ə laɪt ðən ɪt ʃəɾ əv - ðə dɑɹknəs pɹɛst əɡɛns ðə laɪt, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fɔɹs ɪt bæk ɪndə ðə læntɝn - bʌɾ ɛɡwin hæd bɪɡʌn tə fil ðət dɑɹknəs pɹɛsɪŋ əɡɛns hɝ, əz ɪf ɪt hæd weɪt. ɪnstɛd, ʃi kəntɛntəd hɝsɛlf wɪð seɪɪŋ, "bɛləz ɔl ɹaɪt, ən aɪ dɪd nɑt bɹeɪk maɪ nɛk ðə weɪ aɪ dɪzɝv tə."

When Nynaeve came though the Waygate - leading her gray mare slowly, ever so slowly - Egwene almost ran to hug her, and at least half of her feeling was for the lantern Nynaeve carried. The lantern made a smaller pool of light than it should have - the darkness pressed against the light, trying to force it back into the lantern - but Egwene had begun to feel that darkness pressing against her, as if it had weight. Instead, she contented herself with saying, "Bela's all right, and I did not break my neck the way I deserved to."

wʌns ðəɹ hæd bɪn laɪɾ əlɔŋ ðə weɪz, bɪfɔɹ ðə teɪn ɑn ðə paʊɝ wɪð wɪtʃ ðeɪ hæd fɝs bɪn meɪd, ðə teɪn ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn ɑn seɪɾɪn, hæd bɪɡʌn tə kɝʌp ðɛm.

Once there had been light along the Ways, before the taint on the Power with which they had first been made, the taint of the Dark One on saidin, had begun to corrupt them.

nɪneɪiv θɹʌs ðə poʊl ə ðə læntɝn ɪndə hɝ hænz ən tɝn tə pʊl ənʌðɝ fɹəm ʌndɝ əɹ sæɾəl ɡɝθ. "æz lɔŋ əz jə noʊ jə dɪzɝv tə," ʃi mɝmɝd, "ðɛn jə dɪdn dɪzɝv tə." sʌɾənli ʃi tʃʌkəld. "səmtaɪmz aɪ θɪŋk ɪt wɑz seɪɪŋz laɪk ðət mɔɹ ðən ɛniθɪŋ ɛls ðət kɹieɪɾəd ðə taɪɾəl ʌv wɪzdəm. wɛl, hɪɹz ənʌðɝ. jə bɹeɪk jəɹ nɛk, ən əl si ɪt mɛndɪd dʒʌst soʊ aɪ kən bɹeɪk ɪɾ əɡɛn."

Nynaeve thrust the pole of the lantern into her hands and turned to pull another from under her saddle girth. "As long as you know you deserved to," she murmured, "then you didn't deserve to." Suddenly she chuckled. "Sometimes I think it was sayings like that more than anything else that created the title of Wisdom. Well, here's another. You break your neck, and I'll see it mended just so I can break it again."

ɪt wɑz sɛd laɪtli, ən ɛɡwin faʊn hɝsɛlf læfɪŋ, tu - əntɪl ʃi ɹɪkɔld wɛɹ ʃi wɑz. nɪneɪivz əmjuzmən dɪd nɑt læs lɔŋ iðɝ.

It was said lightly, and Egwene found herself laughing, too - until she recalled where she was. Nynaeve's amusement did not last long either.

mɪn ən ɪleɪn keɪm ðoʊ ðə weɪɡeɪt hɛzɪɾəntli, liɾɪŋ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz ən kæɹiɪŋ læntɝnz, ɑbviəsli ɪkspɛktɪŋ tə faɪn mɑnstɝz weɪɾɪŋ ət ðə list. ðeɪ lʊkt ɹɪlivd, ət fɝst, tə faɪnd nʌθɪŋ bʌt dɑɹknəs, bʌt ði əpɹɛsɪvnəs ʌv ɪt sun hæɾ əm ʃɪftɪŋ nɝvəsli fɹəm fʊt tə fʊt. liɑnʒɹɪn ɹipleɪs ði ɑvɛndɪsɔɹə lif ən ɹoʊd θɹu ðə kloʊzɪŋ weɪɡeɪt liɾɪŋ ðə pæk hɔɹs.

Min and Elayne came though the Waygate hesitantly, leading their horses and carrying lanterns, obviously expecting to find monsters waiting at the least. They looked relieved, at first, to find nothing but darkness, but the oppressiveness of it soon had them shifting nervously from foot to foot. Liandrin replaced the Avendesora leaf and rode through the closing Waygate leading the pack horse.

liɑnʒɹɪn dɪd nɑt weɪt fəɹ ðə ɡeɪt tə fɪnɪʃ kloʊzɪŋ, bʌt tɔs ðə lɛd laɪn ə ðə pæk hɔɹs tə mɪn wɪθaʊɾ ə wɝɾ ən stɑɹɾəd əlɔŋ ə waɪt laɪn, dɪmli meɪɾ aʊt baɪ ðə laɪɾ ə hɝ læntɝn, liɾɪŋ ɪndə ðə weɪz. ðə flɔɹ sim tə bi stoʊn, iɾən ən pɪɾəd baɪ æsəd. ɛɡwin skɹæmbəl hɝidli ɑntu bɛləz bæk, bʌt ʃi wɑz noʊ kwɪkɝ tə fɑloʊ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ðən ɛniwʌn ɛls. ðəɹ sim tə bi nʌθɪŋ ɪn ðə wɝld ɪksɛp ðə ɹʌf flɔɹ ʌndɝ ðə hɔɹsəz' hʊvz.

Liandrin did not wait for the gate to finish closing, but tossed the lead line of the pack horse to Min without a word and started along a white line, dimly made out by the light of her lantern, leading into the Ways. The floor seemed to be stone, eaten and pitted by acid. Egwene scrambled hurriedly onto Bela's back, but she was no quicker to follow the Aes Sedai than anyone else. There seemed to be nothing in the world except the rough floor under the horses' hooves.

stʃɹeɪɾ əz ən æɹoʊ ðə waɪt laɪn lɛd θɹu ðə dɑɹk tə ə lɑɹdʒ stoʊn slæb kʌvɝd wɪð oʊɡiɝ skɹɪpt ɪnleɪɾ ɪn sɪlvɝ. ðə seɪm pɑkɪŋ ðət mɑɹk ðə flɔɹ ɔlsoʊ bɹoʊk ðə skɹɪpt ɪn pleɪsəz.

Straight as an arrow the white line led through the dark to a large stone slab covered with Ogier script inlaid in silver. The same pocking that marked the floor also broke the script in places.

"eɪ ɡaɪɾɪŋ," ɪleɪn mɝmɝd, twɪstɪŋ ɪn əɹ sæɾəl tə lʊk ɝaʊn ənizəli. "ɪleɪɾə tɔt mi ə lɪɾəl əbaʊt ðə weɪz. ʃi wəd nɑt seɪ mʌtʃ. nɑɾ ɪnʌf," ʃi æɾəd ɡlʌmli. "ɔɹ meɪbi tu mʌtʃ."

"A Guiding," Elayne murmured, twisting in her saddle to look around uneasily. "Elaida taught me a little about the Ways. She would not say much. Not enough," she added glumly. "Or maybe too much."

kɑmli liɑnʒɹɪn kəmpɛɹd ðə ɡaɪɾɪŋ wɪð ə pɑɹtʃmənt, ðən stʌft ɪt bæk ɪndə ə pɑkəɾ ə hɝ kloʊk bɪfɔɹ ɛɡwin kəd ɡɛɾ ə lʊk.

Calmly Liandrin compared the Guiding with a parchment, then stuffed it back into a pocket of her cloak before Egwene could get a look.

ðɛɹ læntɝnz' laɪt stɑpt əbɹʌpli ɹæðɝ ðən feɪɾɪŋ aʊɾ ət ði ɛdʒəz, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɪnʌf fəɹ ɛɡwin tə si ə θɪk stoʊn bəlʌstʃɹeɪd, iɾən əweɪ ɪn pleɪsəz, əz ði ɛɛs sədaɪ lɛɾ əm əweɪ fɹəm ðə ɡaɪɾɪŋ. ən aɪlənd, ɪleɪn kɔld ɪt; ðə dɑɹknəs meɪd dʒʌdʒɪŋ ði aɪlənz saɪz dɪfəkəlt, bʌɾ ɛɡwin θɔɾ ɪt maɪt bi ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz əkɹɔs.

Their lanterns' light stopped abruptly rather than fading out at the edges, but it was enough for Egwene to see a thick stone balustrade, eaten away in places, as the Aes Sedai led them away from the Guiding. An Island, Elayne called it; the darkness made judging the Island's size difficult, but Egwene thought it might be a hundred paces across.

stoʊn bɹɪdʒəz ən ɹæmps pɪɹs ðə bəlʌstʃɹeɪd, itʃ wɪð ə stoʊn poʊs bɪsaɪɾ ɪt mɑɹkt wɪð ə sɪŋɡəl laɪn ɪn oʊɡiɝ skɹɪpt. ðə bɹɪdʒəz sim tə ɑɹtʃ aʊɾ ɪndə nʌθɪŋ. ðə ɹæmps lɛɾ ʌp əɹ daʊn. ɪt wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl tə si mɔɹ ðən ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ ʌv ɛni ʌv ðɛm, əz ðeɪ ɹoʊd pæst.

Stone bridges and ramps pierced the balustrade, each with a stone post beside it marked with a single line in Ogier script. The bridges seemed to arch out into nothing. The ramps led up or down. It was impossible to see more than the beginning of any of them, as they rode past.

pɔzɪŋ oʊnli tə aɪ ðə stoʊn poʊsts, liɑnʒɹɪn tʊk ə ɹæmp ðət lɛd daʊn, ən kwɪkli ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ bʌt ðə ɹæmp ən ðə dɑɹknəs. ə dæmpənɪŋ saɪləns hʌŋ oʊvɝ ɛvɹiθɪŋ; ɛɡwin hæd ðə filɪŋ ðəɾ ivən ðə klæɾɝ ə ðə hɔɹsəz' hʊvz ɑn ðə ɹʌf stoʊn dɪd nɑt tʃɹævəl vɛɹi fɑɹ bɪɑn ðə laɪt.

Pausing only to eye the stone posts, Liandrin took a ramp that led down, and quickly there was nothing but the ramp and the darkness. A dampening silence hung over everything; Egwene had the feeling that even the clatter of the horses' hooves on the rough stone did not travel very far beyond the light.

daʊn ən daʊn ðə ɹæmp ɹæn, kɝvɪŋ bæk ɑn ɪtsɛlf, əntɪl ɪt ɹitʃt ənʌðɝ aɪlənd, wɪð ɪts bɹoʊkən bəlʌstʃɹeɪd bɪtwin bɹɪdʒəz ən ɹæmps, ɪts ɡaɪɾɪŋ ðət liɑnʒɹɪn kəmpɛɹd wɪð əɹ pɑɹtʃmənt. ði aɪlən sim laɪk sɑləd stoʊn, dʒʌst əz ðə fɝst wʌn hæd. ɛɡwin wɪʃt ʃi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ðət ðə fɝst aɪlənd wɑz dɝɛkli oʊvɝ ðɛɹ hɛdz.

Down and down the ramp ran, curving back on itself, until it reached another Island, with its broken balustrade between bridges and ramps, its Guiding that Liandrin compared with her parchment. The Island seemed like solid stone, just as the first one had. Egwene wished she was not sure that the first Island was directly over their heads.

nɪneɪiv spoʊk ʌp sʌɾənli, vɔɪsɪŋ ɛɡwinz θɔts. hɝ vɔɪs saʊndəd stɛɾi, bʌt ʃi pɔz tə swɑloʊ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ɪt.

Nynaeve spoke up suddenly, voicing Egwene's thoughts. Her voice sounded steady, but she paused to swallow in the middle of it.

"ɪt - ɪt maɪt bi," ɪleɪn sɛd feɪnli. hɝ aɪz ɹoʊld ʌpwɝdz, ən kwɪkli dʒɹɑpt əɡɛn. "ɪleɪɾə sɛz ðə ɹulz ə neɪtʃɝ də nɑt hoʊld ɪn ðə weɪz. ət list, nɑt ðə weɪ ðeɪ də aʊtsaɪd."

"It - it might be," Elayne said faintly. Her eyes rolled upwards, and quickly dropped again. "Elaida says the rules of nature do not hold in the Ways. At least, not the way they do outside."

"laɪt!" mɪn mʌɾɝd, ðən ɹeɪzd əɹ vɔɪs. "haʊ lɔŋ dʒju min əs tə steɪ ɪn hɪɹ?"

"Light!" Min muttered, then raised her voice. "How long do you mean us to stay in here?"

ði ɛɛs sədaɪz hʌni-kʌlɝd bɹeɪdz swʌŋ əz ʃi tɝn tə ɹəɡɑɹd ðɛm. "əntɪl aɪ teɪk jə aʊt," ʃi sɛd flætli. "ðə mɔɹ jə bɑðɝ mi, ðə lɔŋɡɝ ðət wɪl bi." ʃi bɛn bæk tə stʌɾiɪŋ ðə pɑɹtʃmən ən ðə ɡaɪɾɪŋ.

The Aes Sedai's honey-colored braids swung as she turned to regard them. "Until I take you out," she said flatly. "The more you bother me, the longer that will be." She bent back to studying the parchment and the Guiding.

ɛɡwin ən ði ʌðɝz fɛl saɪlənt.

Egwene and the others fell silent.

liɑnʒɹɪn pʊʃt ɑn fɹəm ɡaɪɾɪŋ tə ɡaɪɾɪŋ, baɪ ɹæmps ən bɹɪdʒəz ðət sim tə ɹʌn ənsəpɔɹɾɪd θɹu ði ɛnləs dɑɹk. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ peɪd vɛɹi lɪɾəl hid tə ðə ɹɛst ə ðɛm, ən ɛɡwin faʊn hɝsɛlf wʌndɝɪŋ wɛðɝ liɑnʒɹɪn wəd tɝn bæk tə sɝtʃ ɪf wʌn ə ðɛm fɛl bɪhaɪnd. ði ʌðɝz pɝhæps hæd ðə seɪm θɔt, fəɹ ðeɪ ɔl ɹoʊd bʌntʃt taɪtli ɑn ðə dɑɹk mɛɹz hilz.

Liandrin pushed on from Guiding to Guiding, by ramps and bridges that seemed to run unsupported through the endless dark. The Aes Sedai paid very little heed to the rest of them, and Egwene found herself wondering whether Liandrin would turn back to search if one of them fell behind. The others perhaps had the same thought, for they all rode bunched tightly on the dark mare's heels.

ɛɡwin wɑz sɝpɹaɪz tə ɹilaɪz ðət ʃi stɪl fɛl ði ətʃɹækʃən ə seɪaɪdɑɹ, boʊθ ðə pɹɛzəns ə ðə fimeɪl hæf ə ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs ən ðə dɪzaɪɝ tə tʌtʃ ɪt, tə tʃænəl ɪts floʊ. sʌmhaʊ, ʃi hæd θɔt ðə ʃædoʊz teɪn ɑn ðə weɪz wəd haɪɾ ɪt fɹəm hɝ. ʃi kəd sɛns ðət teɪnt, æftɝ ə fæʃən. ɪt wɑz feɪn ən hæd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð seɪaɪdɑɹ, bʌt ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ðət ɹitʃɪŋ fəɹ ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs hɪɹ wəd bi laɪk bɛɹɪŋ əɹ ɑɹm tə faʊl, ɡɹisi smoʊk ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə ɹitʃ ə klin kʌp. wʌtɛvɝ ʃi dɪd wəd bi teɪntɪd. fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm ɪn wiks ʃi hæd noʊ tʃɹʌbəl əɾ ɔl ɪn ɹɪzɪstɪŋ ði ətʃɹækʃən ə seɪaɪdɑɹ.

Egwene was surprised to realize that she still felt the attraction of saidar, both the presence of the female half of the True Source and the desire to touch it, to channel its flow. Somehow, she had thought the Shadow's taint on the Ways would hide it from her. She could sense that taint, after a fashion. It was faint and had nothing to do with saidar, but she was sure that reaching for the True Source here would be like baring her arm to foul, greasy smoke in order to reach a clean cup. Whatever she did would be tainted. For the first time in weeks she had no trouble at all in resisting the attraction of saidar.

ɪt wɑz wɛl ɪndə wʌt wʊɾə bɪn naɪɾ ɪn ðə wɝld aʊtsaɪd ðə weɪz wɛn, ɑn ən aɪlənd, liɑnʒɹɪn əbɹʌpli dɪsmaʊntɪɾ ən ənaʊns ðət ðeɪ wəd hɔl fəɹ sʌpɝ ən slip, ən ðət ðəɹ wɑz fuɾ ɑn ðə pæk hɔɹs.

It was well into what would have been night in the world outside the Ways when, on an Island, Liandrin abruptly dismounted and announced that they would halt for supper and sleep, and that there was food on the pack horse.

"pɑɹsəl ɪɾ aʊt," ʃi sɛd, nɑt bɑðɝɪŋ tə əsaɪn ðə tæsk. "ɪt wɪl teɪk əs ðə bɛɾɝ pɑɹɾ ə tu deɪz tə ɹitʃ toʊmən hɛd. aɪ wəd nɑɾ əv jə ɝaɪv hʌŋɡɹi ɪf jə wɝ tu fulɪʃ nɑt tə bɹɪŋ fud jʊɹsɛlvz." bɹɪskli ʃi ənsæɾəld ən hɑbəld əɹ mɛɹ, bʌt ðən ʃi sæt daʊn ɑn əɹ sæɾəl ən weɪɾəd fəɹ wʌn ə ðɛm tə bɹɪŋ əɹ sʌmθɪŋ tə it.

"Parcel it out," she said, not bothering to assign the task. "It will take us the better part of two days to reach Toman Head. I would not have you arrive hungry if you were too foolish not to bring food yourselves." Briskly she unsaddled and hobbled her mare, but then she sat down on her saddle and waited for one of them to bring her something to eat.

ɪleɪn tʊk liɑnʒɹɪn əɹ flætbɹɛɾ ən tʃiz. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ meɪɾ ɪɾ ɑbviəs ðət ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑn ðɛɹ kʌmpəni, soʊ ðə ɹɛst ə ðɛm eɪt ðɛɹ bɹɛɾ ən tʃiz ə lɪɾəl əpɑɹt fɹəm hɝ, sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ sæɾəlz dʒɹɔn kloʊs təɡɛðɝ. ðə dɑɹknəs bɪɑn ðɛɹ læntɝnz meɪɾ ə pʊɹ sɔs.

Elayne took Liandrin her flatbread and cheese. The Aes Sedai made it obvious that she did not want their company, so the rest of them ate their bread and cheese a little apart from her, sitting on their saddles drawn close together. The darkness beyond their lanterns made a poor sauce.

æftɝ ə taɪm, ɛɡwin sɛd, "liɑnʒɹɪn sədaɪ, wʌɾ ɪf wi ɪnkaʊntɝ ðə blæk wɪnd?" mɪn maʊðd ðə wɝd kwɛstʃənɪŋli, bʌɾ ɪleɪn ɡeɪv ə skwik. "mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ sɛɾ ɪt kəd nɑt bi kɪld, əɹ ivən hɝt vɛɹi mʌtʃ, ən aɪ kən fil ðə teɪn ɑn ðɪs pleɪs weɪɾɪŋ tə twɪst ɛniθɪŋ wi də wɪð ðə paʊɝ."

After a time, Egwene said, "Liandrin Sedai, what if we encounter the Black Wind?" Min mouthed the word questioningly, but Elayne gave a squeak. "Moiraine Sedai said it could not be killed, or even hurt very much, and I can feel the taint on this place waiting to twist anything we do with the Power."

"ju wɪl nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ əz θɪŋk ə ðə sɔɹs ənlɛs aɪ tɛl jə tə," liɑnʒɹɪn sɛd ʃɑɹpli. "waɪ, ɪf wʌn sətʃ əz jə tʃɹaɪd tə tʃænəl hɪɹ, ɪn ðə weɪz, jə maɪt wɛl ɡoʊ əz mæɾ əz ə mæn. juv nɑt ðə tʃɹeɪnɪŋ tə dil wɪð ðə teɪn ə ðoʊz mɛn u meɪd ðɪs. ɪf ðə blæk wɪn əpɪɹz, əl dil wɪð ɪt." ʃi pɝst əɹ lɪps, stʌɾiɪŋ ə lʌmp ʌv waɪt tʃiz. "mɔɪɹeɪn dʌz nɑt noʊ soʊ mʌtʃ əz ʃi θɪŋks." ʃi pɑp ðə tʃiz ɪndə hɝ maʊθ wɪð ə smaɪl.

"You will not so much as think of the Source unless I tell you to," Liandrin said sharply. "Why, if one such as you tried to channel here, in the Ways, you might well go as mad as a man. You have not the training to deal with the taint of those men who made this. If the Black Wind appears, I will deal with it." She pursed her lips, studying a lump of white cheese. "Moiraine does not know so much as she thinks." She popped the cheese into her mouth with a smile.

"aɪ də nɑt laɪk hɝ," ɛɡwin mʌɾɝd, loʊ ɪnʌf tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd nɑt hɪɹ.

"I do not like her," Egwene muttered, low enough to make sure the Aes Sedai could not hear.

"ɪf mɔɪɹeɪn kən wɝk wɪð hɝ," nɪneɪiv sɛd kwaɪətli, "soʊ kən wi. nɑt ðəɾ aɪ laɪk mɔɪɹeɪn ɛni bɛɾɝ ðən aɪ də liɑnʒɹɪn, bʌɾ ɪf ðəɹ mɛɾəlɪŋ wɪð ɹænd ən ði ʌðɝz əɡɛn. . . ." ʃi fɛl saɪlənt, hɪtʃɪŋ əɹ kloʊk ʌp. ðə dɑɹknəs wɑz nɑt koʊld, bʌɾ ɪt simd əz ɪf ɪt ʃəd bi.

"If Moiraine can work with her," Nynaeve said quietly, "so can we. Not that I like Moiraine any better than I do Liandrin, but if they're meddling with Rand and the others again. . . ." She fell silent, hitching her cloak up. The darkness was not cold, but it seemed as if it should be.

"wʌɾ ɪz ðɪs blæk wɪnd?" mɪn æskt. wən ɪleɪn hæɾ ɪkspleɪnd, wɪð ə ɡɹeɪt dil ʌv wʌɾ ɪleɪɾə hæd sɛɾ ən wʌɾ əɹ mʌðɝ hæd sɛd, mɪn saɪd. "ðə pæɾɝn əz ə ɡɹeɪt dil tə ænsɝ fɔɹ. aɪ doʊnt noʊ ðəɾ ɛni mæn ɪz wɝθ ðɪs."

"What is this Black Wind?" Min asked. When Elayne had explained, with a great deal of what Elaida had said and what her mother had said, Min sighed. "The Pattern has a great deal to answer for. I don't know that any man is worth this."

"ju dɪd nɑɾ əv tə kʌm," ɛɡwin ɹimaɪndəd hɝ. "ju cʊɾə ɡɔn əɾ ɛni taɪm. noʊ wʌn wʊɾə tʃɹaɪd tə stɑp jə livɪŋ ðə taʊɝ."

"You did not have to come," Egwene reminded her. "You could have gone at any time. No one would have tried to stop you leaving the Tower."

"oʊ, aɪ cʊɾə wɑndɝɾ ɔf," mɪn sɛd ɹaɪli. "æz izəli əz ju, əɹ ɪleɪn. ðə pæɾɝn dʌzn mʌtʃ kɛɹ wʌt wi wɑnt. ɛɡwin, wʌɾ ɪf, æftɝ ɔl jə ɑɹ ɡoʊɪŋ θɹu fəɹ hɪm, ɹænd dʌzn mɛɹi ju? wʌɾ ɪf i mɛɹiz səm wʊmən juv nɛvɝ sin bɪfɔɹ, əɹ ɪleɪn, əɹ mi? wʌt ðɛn?"

"Oh, I could have wandered off," Min said wryly. "As easily as you, or Elayne. The Pattern doesn't much care what we want. Egwene, what if, after all you are going through for him, Rand doesn't marry you? What if he marries some woman you've never seen before, or Elayne, or me? What then?"

ɪleɪn tʃɔɹɾəld. "mʌðɝ wəd nɛvɝ əpɹuv."

Elayne chortled. "Mother would never approve."

ɛɡwin wɑz saɪlən fəɹ ə taɪm. ɹænd maɪt nɑt lɪv tə mɛɹi ɛniwʌn. ən ɪf i dɪd. . . . ʃi kəd nɑɾ ɪmædʒən ɹænd hɝɾɪŋ ɛniwʌn. nɑɾ ivən æftɝ hiz ɡɔn mæd? ðəɹ hæd tə bi səm weɪ tə stɑp ðæt, səm weɪ tə tʃeɪnʒ ɪt; ɛɛs sədaɪ nu soʊ mʌtʃ, kəd də soʊ mʌtʃ. ɪf ðeɪ kəd stɑp ɪt, waɪ doʊn ðeɪ? ði oʊnli ænsɝ wɑz kəz ðeɪ kəd nɑt, ən ðət wɑz nɑt ðə wʌn ʃi wɑntəd.

Egwene was silent for a time. Rand might not live to marry anyone. And if he did. . . . She could not imagine Rand hurting anyone. Not even after he's gone mad? There had to be some way to stop that, some way to change it; Aes Sedai knew so much, could do so much. If they could stop it, why don't they? The only answer was because they could not, and that was not the one she wanted.

ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə pʊt laɪtnəs ɪn əɹ vɔɪs. "aɪ doʊn səpoʊz əl mɛɹi hɪm. ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛldəm də mɛɹi, jə noʊ. bʌɾ aɪ wəd nɑt sɛt maɪ hɑɹɾ ɑn ɪm ɪf wɝ ju. əɹ ju, ɪleɪn. aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk. . . ." hɝ vɔɪs kɑt, ən ʃi kɔf tə kʌvɝ ɪt. "aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk hɪl ɛvɝ mɛɹi. bʌɾ ɪf i dʌz, aɪ wɪʃ wɛl tə huɛvɝ ɛnz ʌp wɪð hɪm, ivən wʌn ə ju." ʃi θɔt ʃi saʊndəɾ əz ɪf ʃi mɛn ɪt. "hi ɪz stʌbɝn əz ə mjul, ən ɹɔŋhɛɾɪd tə ə fɔlt, bʌt hiz dʒɛntəl." hɝ vɔɪs ʃʊk, bʌt ʃi mænədʒ tə tɝn ðə kweɪvɝ ɪndə ə læf.

She tried to put lightness in her voice. "I don't suppose I will marry him. Aes Sedai seldom do marry, you know. But I would not set my heart on him if were you. Or you, Elayne. I do not think. . . ." Her voice caught, and she coughed to cover it. "I do not think he will ever marry. But if he does, I wish well to whoever ends up with him, even one of you." She thought she sounded as if she meant it. "He is stubborn as a mule, and wrongheaded to a fault, but he is gentle." Her voice shook, but she managed to turn the quaver into a laugh.

"haʊɛvɝ mʌtʃ jə seɪ jə də nɑt kɛɹ," ɪleɪn sɛd, "aɪ θɪŋk juɾ əpɹuv lɛs ðən mʌðɝ wʊd. hiz ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ, ɛɡwin. mɔɹ ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ ðən ɛni mæn aɪv ɛvɝ mɛt, ivən ɪf hiz ə ʃɛpɝd. ɪf jə ɑɹ sɪli ɪnʌf tə θɹoʊ hɪm əweɪ, jəl əv oʊnli jɝsɛlf tə bleɪm ɪf aɪ dɪsaɪd tə feɪs daʊn jə ən mʌðɝ boʊθ. ɪt wəd nɑt bi ðə fɝs taɪm ðə pɹɪns ʌv ændɝ hæd noʊ taɪɾəl bɪfɔɹ i wɛd. bʌt jə woʊn bi ðət sɪli, soʊ doʊn tʃɹaɪ tə pɹitɛn jə wɪl. noʊ daʊt jəl tʃuz ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ, ən meɪk ɪm wʌn ə jəɹ wɔɹɾɝz. ði oʊnli ɡɹinz aɪ noʊ wɪð oʊnli wʌn wɔɹɾɝ ɑɹ mɛɹid tə ðɛm."

"However much you say you do not care," Elayne said, "I think you'd approve less than Mother would. He is interesting, Egwene. More interesting than any man I've ever met, even if he is a shepherd. If you are silly enough to throw him away, you will have only yourself to blame if I decide to face down you and Mother both. It would not be the first time the Prince of Andor had no title before he wed. But you won't be that silly, so don't try to pretend you will. No doubt you will choose the Green Ajah, and make him one of your Warders. The only Greens I know with only one Warder are married to them."

ɛɡwin meɪd hɝsɛlf ɡoʊ əlɔŋ wɪð ɪt, seɪɪŋ ɪf ʃi dɪd bɪkʌm ə ɡɹin ʃi wʊɾə tɛn wɔɹɾɝz.

Egwene made herself go along with it, saying if she did become a Green she would have ten Warders.

mɪn wɑtʃt hɝ, fɹaʊnɪŋ, ən nɪneɪiv wɑtʃt mɪn θɔtfəli. ðeɪ ɔl fɛl saɪlən baɪ ðə taɪm ðeɪ tʃeɪnʒd ɪndə mɔɹ suɾəbəl kloʊðz fəɹ tʃɹævlɪŋ, fɹəm ðɛɹ sæɾəlbæɡz. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ izi, kipɪŋ spɪɹəts ʌp ɪn ðət pleɪs.

Min watched her, frowning, and Nynaeve watched Min thoughtfully. They all fell silent by the time they changed into more suitable clothes for traveling, from their saddlebags. It was not easy, keeping spirits up in that place.

slip keɪm sloʊli tə ɛɡwin, fɪtfəli, ən ɪt wɑz fɪld wɪð bæd dʒɹimz. ʃi dɪd nɑt dʒɹim ə ɹænd, bʌɾ ə ðə mæn huz aɪz wɝ faɪɝ. hɪz feɪs wɑz nɑt mæsk ðɪs taɪm, ən ɪt wɑz hɔɹəbəl wɪð ɔlmoʊs hil bɝnz. hi oʊnli lʊkt əɾ əɹ ən læft, bʌt ðət wɑz wɝs ðən ðə dʒɹimz ðət fɑloʊd, ðə dʒɹimz ə biɪŋ lɔst ɪn ðə weɪz fɝɛvɝ, ðə wʌnz wɛɹ ðə blæk wɪnd wɑz tʃeɪsɪŋ hɝ. ʃi wɑz ɡɹeɪtfəl wən ðə toʊ ʌv liɑnʒɹɪnz ɹaɪɾɪŋ but dʌɡ ɪndə hɝ ɹɪbz tə weɪkən hɝ; ʃi fɛlt əz ɪf ʃi hæd nɑt slɛpt əɾ ɔl.

Sleep came slowly to Egwene, fitfully, and it was filled with bad dreams. She did not dream of Rand, but of the man whose eyes were fire. His face was not masked this time, and it was horrible with almost healed burns. He only looked at her and laughed, but that was worse than the dreams that followed, the dreams of being lost in the Ways forever, the ones where the Black Wind was chasing her. She was grateful when the toe of Liandrin's riding boot dug into her ribs to waken her; she felt as if she had not slept at all.

liɑnʒɹɪn pʊʃt əm hɑɹd θɹu ðə nɛks deɪ, əɹ wʌt pæs fəɹ deɪ, wɪð oʊnli ðɛɹ læntɝnz fəɹ ə sʌn, nɑt lɛɾɪŋ əm stɑp fəɹ slip əntɪl ðeɪ wɝ sweɪɪŋ ɪn ðɛɹ sæɾəlz. stoʊn meɪɾ ə hɑɹd bɛd, bʌt liɑnʒɹɪn ɹaʊzd əm ɹuθləsli æftɝ ə fju aʊɝz, hɑɹdli weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ əm tə maʊn bɪfɔɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɑn. ɹæmps ən bɹɪdʒəz, aɪlənz ən ɡaɪɾɪŋz. ɛɡwin sɔ soʊ mɛni ʌv əm ɪn ðət pɪtʃ-dɑɹk ðət ʃi lɔs kaʊnt. ʃi hæd lɔŋ sɪns lɔst ɛni kaʊn ʌv aʊɝz əɹ ə deɪz. liɑnʒɹɪn əlaʊɾ oʊnli bɹif hɔls tə iɾ ən ɹɛs ðə hɔɹsəz, ən ðə dɑɹknəs weɪd daʊn ɑn ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz. ðeɪ slʌmpt ɪn ðɛɹ sæɾəlz laɪk sæks ʌv ɡɹeɪn, ɪksɛp fəɹ liɑnʒɹɪn. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ simd ʌnəfɛktɪd baɪ taɪɹədnəs, əɹ ðə dɑɹk. ʃi wɑz əz fɹɛʃ əz ʃi hæd bɪn bæk ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ən əz koʊld. ʃi wəd nɑt lɛɾ ɛniwʌn ɡlɪmps ðə pɑɹtʃmənt ʃi kəmpɛɹd tə ðə ɡaɪɾɪŋz, stʌfɪŋ ɪɾ əweɪ wɪð ə kɝt, "ɪɾ ɪz nʌθɪŋ jə wəɾ ʌndɝstænd," wən nɪneɪiv æskt.

Liandrin pushed them hard through the next day, or what passed for day, with only their lanterns for a sun, not letting them stop for sleep until they were swaying in their saddles. Stone made a hard bed, but Liandrin roused them ruthlessly after a few hours, hardly waiting for them to mount before riding on. Ramps and bridges, Islands and Guidings. Egwene saw so many of them in that pitch-dark that she lost count. She had long since lost any count of hours or of days. Liandrin allowed only brief halts to eat and rest the horses, and the darkness weighed down on their shoulders. They slumped in their saddles like sacks of grain, except for Liandrin. The Aes Sedai seemed unaffected by tiredness, or the dark. She was as fresh as she had been back in the White Tower, and as cold. She would not let anyone glimpse the parchment she compared to the Guidings, stuffing it away with a curt, "It is nothing you would understand," when Nynaeve asked.

ən ðɛn, waɪl ɛɡwin blɪŋkt wɛɹəli, liɑnʒɹɪn wɑz ɹaɪɾɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ə ɡaɪɾɪŋ, nɑt təwɔɹɾ ənʌðɝ bɹɪdʒ əɹ ɹæmp, bʌt daʊn ə pɪɾəd waɪt laɪn ðət lɛɾ ɔf ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs. ɛɡwin stɛɹɾ əɾ əɹ fɹɛnz, ən ðən ðeɪ ɔl hɝid tə fɑloʊ. əhɛd, baɪ ðə laɪɾ ə hɝ læntɝn, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ɹimuvɪŋ ði ɑvɛndɪsɔɹə lif fɹəm ðə kɑɹvɪŋz ɑn ə weɪɡeɪt.

And then, while Egwene blinked wearily, Liandrin was riding away from a Guiding, not toward another bridge or ramp, but down a pitted white line that led off into the darkness. Egwene stared at her friends, and then they all hurried to follow. Ahead, by the light of her lantern, the Aes Sedai was already removing the Avendesora leaf from the carvings on a Waygate.

"wi ɑɹ hɪɹ," liɑnʒɹɪn sɛd, smaɪlɪŋ. "aɪ hæv bɹɔt jə ət læs tə wɛɹ jə mʌst ɡoʊ."

"We are here," Liandrin said, smiling. "I have brought you at last to where you must go."


tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾi


CHAPTER 40

deɪmeɪn


Damane

ɛɡwin dɪsmaʊntɪɾ əz ðə weɪɡeɪɾ oʊpənd, ən wən liɑnʒɹɪn moʊʃən əm θɹu, ʃi lɛd ðə ʃæɡi mɛɹ kɛɹfəli aʊt. ivən soʊ, ʃi ən bɛlə boʊθ stʌmbəld ɪn bɹʌʃ flæɾənd baɪ ði oʊpənɪŋ weɪɡeɪɾ əz ðeɪ sʌɾənli sim tə bi muvɪŋ ivən mɔɹ sloʊli. ə skɹin ə dɛns ʃɹʌbz hæd sɝaʊndəɾ ən hɪɾən ðə weɪɡeɪt. ðəɹ wɝ oʊnli ə fju tʃɹiz kloʊs baɪ, ən ə mɔɹnɪŋ bɹiz ɹʌfəl foʊlɪdʒ wɪð ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ kʌlɝ ðən ðə livz hæd hæɾ ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn.

Egwene dismounted as the Waygate opened, and when Liandrin motioned them through, she led the shaggy mare carefully out. Even so, she and Bela both stumbled in brush flattened by the opening Waygate as they suddenly seemed to be moving even more slowly. A screen of dense shrubs had surrounded and hidden the Waygate. There were only a few trees close by, and a morning breeze ruffled foliage with a little more color than the leaves had had in Tar Valon.

wɑtʃɪŋ əɹ fɹɛnz ɪmɝdʒ æftɝ hɝ, ʃi hæd bɪn stændɪŋ ðəɹ ə ɡʊd mɪnət bɪfɔɹ ʃi bɪkeɪm əwɛɹ ðəɾ ʌðɝz wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi ðɛɹ, dʒʌst aʊɾ ə saɪɾ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə ɡeɪts. wən ʃi dɪd noʊɾəs əm ʃi stɛɹɾ ənsɝteɪnli; ðeɪ wɝ əz ɑɾ ə ɡɹup əz ʃi hæɾ ɛvɝ sin, ən ʃi hæd hɝd tu mɛni ɹumɝz ə ðə wɔɹ ɑn toʊmən hɛd.

Watching her friends emerge after her, she had been standing there a good minute before she became aware that others were already there, just out of sight on the other side of the gates. When she did notice them she stared uncertainly; they were as odd a group as she had ever seen, and she had heard too many rumors of the war on Toman Head.

ɑɹmɝd mɛn, ət lis fɪfti ʌv ðɛm, wɪð oʊvɝlæpɪŋ stil pleɪts daʊn ðɛɹ tʃɛsts ən dʌl blæk hɛlməts ʃeɪp laɪk ɪnsɛks' hɛdz, sæt ðɛɹ sæɾəlz əɹ stʊd bɪsaɪd ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz, stɛɹɪŋ əɾ əɹ ən ði ɪmɝdʒɪŋ wɪmən, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə weɪɡeɪt, mʌɾɝɪŋ əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz. ði oʊnli bæɹhɛɾɪd mæn əmʌŋ ðɛm, ə tɔl, dɑɹk-feɪst, hʊk-noʊz fɛloʊ stændɪŋ wɪð ə ɡɪldɪd-ænd-peɪntəd hɛlməɾ ɑn ɪz hɪp, lʊkt əstɑnɪʃt ət wʌɾ i wɑz siɪŋ. ðəɹ wɝ wɪmən wɪð ðə soʊlʒɝz, tu. tu wɔɹ pleɪn, dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ dʒɹɛsəz ən waɪd sɪlvɝ kɑlɝz, ən stʊd stɛɹɪŋ ɪntɛnli ət ðoʊz kʌmɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə weɪɡeɪt, itʃ wɪð ənʌðɝ wʊmən kloʊs bɪhaɪn əɹ əz ɪf ɹɛɾi tə spik ɪndə hɝ ɪɹ. tu ʌðɝ wɪmən, stændɪŋ ə lɪɾəl əpɑɹt, wɔɹ waɪd, dɪvaɪɾəd skɝts ðət keɪm wɛl ʃɔɹɾ ə ðɛɹ æŋkəlz, ən pænəlz ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð fɔɹk laɪtnɪŋ boʊls ɑn ðɛɹ boʊsəmz ən skɝts. ɑɾəst ʌv ɔl wɑz ðə læst wʊmən, ɹɪklaɪnɪŋ ɑn ə pɑlɑnkwɪn bɔɹn baɪ eɪt mʌskjəlɝ, bɛɹ-tʃɛstəd mɛn ɪn bæɡi blæk tʃɹaʊzɝz. ðə saɪdz ə hɝ skælp wɝ ʃeɪv soʊ ðəɾ oʊnli ə waɪd kɹɛst ə blæk hɛɹ ɹɪmeɪn tə fɔl daʊn əɹ bæk. ə lɔŋ, kɹim-kʌlɝd ɹoʊb wɝkt ɪn flaʊɝz ən bɝdz ɑn blu oʊvəlz wɑz kɛɹfəli ɝeɪnʒd tə ʃoʊ hɝ skɝts ə pliɾɪd waɪt, ən əɹ fɪŋɡɝneɪlz wɝ ə ɡʊɾ ɪntʃ lɔŋ, ðə fɝs tu ɑn itʃ hæn lækɝd blu.

Armored men, at least fifty of them, with overlapping steel plates down their chests and dull black helmets shaped like insects' heads, sat their saddles or stood beside their horses, staring at her and the emerging women, staring at the Waygate, muttering among themselves. The only bareheaded man among them, a tall, dark-faced, hook-nosed fellow standing with a gilded-and-painted helmet on his hip, looked astonished at what he was seeing. There were women with the soldiers, too. Two wore plain, dark gray dresses and wide silver collars, and stood staring intently at those coming out of the Waygate, each with another woman close behind her as if ready to speak into her ear. Two other women, standing a little apart, wore wide, divided skirts that came well short of their ankles, and panels embroidered with forked lightning bolts on their bosoms and skirts. Oddest of all was the last woman, reclining on a palanquin borne by eight muscular, bare-chested men in baggy black trousers. The sides of her scalp were shaved so that only a wide crest of black hair remained to fall down her back. A long, cream-colored robe worked in flowers and birds on blue ovals was carefully arranged to show her skirts of pleated white, and her fingernails were a good inch long, the first two on each hand lacquered blue.

"liɑnʒɹɪn sədaɪ," ɛɡwin æskt ənizəli, "du jə noʊ hu ðiz pipəl ɑɹ?" hɝ fɹɛnz fɪŋɡɝd ðɛɹ ɹeɪnz əz ɪf wʌndɝɪŋ wɛðɝ tə maʊn ən ɹʌn, bʌt liɑnʒɹɪn ɹipleɪs ði ɑvɛndɪsɔɹə lif ən stɛp fɔɹwɝd kɑnfəɾəntli əz ðə weɪɡeɪt bɪɡæn tə kloʊz.

"Liandrin Sedai," Egwene asked uneasily, "do you know who these people are?" Her friends fingered their reins as if wondering whether to mount and run, but Liandrin replaced the Avendesora leaf and stepped forward confidently as the Waygate began to close.

"ðə haɪ leɪɾi sjuɹɔθ?" liɑnʒɹɪn sɛd, meɪkɪŋ ɪt hæfweɪ bɪtwin ə kwɛstʃən ən steɪtmənt.

"The High Lady Suroth?" Liandrin said, making it halfway between a question and statement.

ðə wɪmən ɑn ðə pɑlɑnkwɪn nɑɾəd fɹækʃənəli. "ju ɑɹ liɑnʒɹɪn." hɝ spitʃ wɑz slɝd, ən ɪt tʊk ɛɡwin ə moʊmən tə ʌndɝstænd. "ɛɛs sədaɪ," sjuɹɔθ æɾəd wɪð ə twɪs tə hɝ lɪps, ən ə mɝmɝ ɹoʊz əmʌŋ ðə soʊlʒɝz. "wi mʌs bi dʌn hɪɹ kwɪkli, liɑnʒɹɪn. ðəɹ ɑɹ pətʃɹoʊlz, ən ɪt wəd nɑt də tə bi faʊnd. jə wəɾ ɛndʒɔɪ ði ətɛnʃənz ə ðə sikɝz fəɹ tʃɹuθ noʊ mɔɹ ðən aɪ. aɪ min tə bi bæk ɪn fɑlm bɪfɔɹ tʃɹɑk noʊz aɪm ɡɔn."

The women on the palanquin nodded fractionally. "You are Liandrin." Her speech was slurred, and it took Egwene a moment to understand. "Aes Sedai," Suroth added with a twist to her lips, and a murmur rose among the soldiers. "We must be done here quickly, Liandrin. There are patrols, and it would not do to be found. You would enjoy the attentions of the Seekers for Truth no more than I. I mean to be back in Falme before Turak knows I am gone."

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt?" nɪneɪiv dɪmændəd. "wʌɾ ɪz ʃi tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt, liɑnʒɹɪn?"

"What are you talking about?" Nynaeve demanded. "What is she talking about, Liandrin?"

liɑnʒɹɪn leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn nɪneɪivz ʃoʊldɝ ən wʌn ɑn ɛɡwinz. "ðiz ɑɹ ðə tu ʌv hum jə wɝ toʊld. ən ðəɹ ɪz ənʌðɝ." ʃi nɑɾəd təwɔɹɾ ɪleɪn. "ʃi ɪz ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ʌv ændɝ."

Liandrin laid a hand on Nynaeve's shoulder and one on Egwene's. "These are the two of whom you were told. And there is another." She nodded toward Elayne. "She is the Daughter-Heir of Andor."

ðə tu wɪmən wɪð ðə laɪtnɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ dʒɹɛsəz wɝ əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ ðə pɑɹɾi ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə weɪɡeɪt - ðeɪ kæɹid kɔɪlz ə səm sɪlvɝi mɛɾəl ɪn ðɛɹ hænz, ɛɡwin noʊɾəst - ən ðə bæɹhɛɾɪd soʊlʒɝ keɪm wɪð ðɛm. hi dɪd nɑt pʊɾ ə hænd nɪɹ ðə sɔɹd hɪl stɪkɪŋ ʌp əbʌv ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, ən i wɔɹ ə kæʒəwəl smaɪl, bʌɾ ɛɡwin stɪl wɑtʃt ɪm nɛɹoʊli. liɑnʒɹɪn ɡeɪv noʊ saɪn ʌv ædʒəteɪʃən; ʌðɝwaɪz ɛɡwin wʊɾə dʒʌmpt ɑntu bɛlə ɹaɪt ðɛn.

The two women with the lightning on their dresses were approaching the party in front of the Waygate - they carried coils of some silvery metal in their hands, Egwene noticed - and the bareheaded soldier came with them. He did not put a hand near the sword hilt sticking up above his shoulder, and he wore a casual smile, but Egwene still watched him narrowly. Liandrin gave no sign of agitation; otherwise Egwene would have jumped onto Bela right then.

"liɑnʒɹɪn sədaɪ," ʃi sɛɾ ɝdʒənli, "hu ɑɹ ðiz pipəl? ɑɹ ðeɪ hɪɹ tə hɛlp ɹænd ən ði ʌðɝz, tu?"

"Liandrin Sedai," she said urgently, "who are these people? Are they here to help Rand and the others, too?"

ðə hʊk-noʊz mæn sʌɾənli siz mɪn ən ɪleɪn baɪ ðə skɹʌfs ə ðɛɹ nɛks, ən ɪn ðə nɛkst ɪnstən ɛvɹiθɪŋ sim tə hæpən ət wʌns. ðə mæn jɛld ə kɝs, ən ə wʊmən skɹimd, əɹ pɝhæps mɔɹ ðən wʌn wʊmən; ɛɡwin kəd nɑt bi ʃʊɹ. əbɹʌpli ðə bɹiz wɑz ə ɡeɪl ðət wɪpt əweɪ liɑnʒɹɪnz æŋɡɹi ʃaʊɾ ɪn klaʊdz ə dɝɾ ən livz ən meɪd ðə tʃɹiz bɛn ən ɡɹoʊn. hɔɹsəz ɹɪɹɾ ən wɪnid ʃɹɪli. ən wʌn ə ðə wɪmən ɹitʃt aʊɾ ən fæsən sʌmθɪŋ ɝaʊn ɛɡwinz nɛk.

The hook-nosed man suddenly seized Min and Elayne by the scruffs of their necks, and in the next instant everything seemed to happen at once. The man yelled a curse, and a woman screamed, or perhaps more than one woman; Egwene could not be sure. Abruptly the breeze was a gale that whipped away Liandrin's angry shout in clouds of dirt and leaves and made the trees bend and groan. Horses reared and whinnied shrilly. And one of the women reached out and fastened something around Egwene's neck.

kloʊk flæpɪŋ laɪk ə seɪl, ɛɡwin bɹeɪst əɡɛns ðə wɪn ən tʌɡd ət wʌt fɛlt laɪk ə kɑlɝ ə smuð mɛɾəl. ɪt wəd nɑt bʌdʒ; ʌndɝ əɹ fɹæntɪk fɪŋɡɝz, ɪt fɛlt ɔl ʌv wʌn pis, ðoʊ ʃi nu ɪt hæd tə hæv səm kaɪndə klæsp. ðə sɪlvɝi kɔɪlz ðə wʊmən hæd kæɹid naʊ tʃɹeɪld oʊvɝ ɛɡwinz ʃoʊldɝ, ðɛɹ ʌðɝ ɛn dʒɔɪnɪŋ ə bɹaɪt bɹeɪsləɾ ɑn ðə wʊmənz lɛft ɹɪst. bɔlɪŋ əɹ fɪs taɪtli, ɛɡwin hɪt ðə wʊmən əz hɑɹɾ əz ʃi kʊd, ɹaɪɾ ɪn əɹ aɪ - ən stæɡɝɾ ən fɛl tə hɝ niz hɝsɛlf, hɛd ɹɪŋɪŋ. ɪt fɛlt əz ɪf ə lɑɹdʒ mæn hæd stʃɹʌk əɹ ɪn ðə feɪs.

Cloak flapping like a sail, Egwene braced against the wind and tugged at what felt like a collar of smooth metal. It would not budge; under her frantic fingers, it felt all of one piece, though she knew it had to have some kind of clasp. The silvery coils the woman had carried now trailed over Egwene's shoulder, their other end joining a bright bracelet on the woman's left wrist. Balling her fist tightly, Egwene hit the woman as hard as she could, right in her eye - and staggered and fell to her knees herself, head ringing. It felt as if a large man had struck her in the face.

wən ʃi kəd si stʃɹeɪt wʌns mɔɹ, ðə wɪn hæd daɪd. ə nʌmbɝ ə hɔɹsəz wɑndɝd lus, bɛlə ən ɪleɪnz mɛɹ əmʌŋ ðɛm, ən səm ə ðə soʊlʒɝz wɝ kɝsɪŋ ən pɪkɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz ʌp ɔf ðə ɡɹaʊnd. liɑnʒɹɪn wɑz kɑmli bɹʌʃɪŋ dʌst ən livz fɹəm əɹ dʒɹɛs. mɪn nɛlt, səpɔɹɾɪŋ hɝsɛlf wɪð əɹ hænz, ɡɹɑdʒəli tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹaɪz fɝðɝ. ðə hʊk-noʊz mæn stʊɾ oʊvɝ hɝ, hɪz hæn dʒɹɪpɪŋ blʌd. mɪnz naɪf leɪ dʒʌst aʊɾ ə hɝ ɹitʃ, ðə bleɪd steɪn ɹɛɾ əlɔŋ wʌn saɪd. nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn wɝ noʊwɛɹ tə bi sin, ən nɪneɪivz mɛɹ wɑz ɡɔn, tu. soʊ wɝ səm ə ðə soʊlʒɝz, ən wʌn ə ðə pɛɹz ʌv wɪmən. ði ʌðɝ tu wɝ stɪl ðɛɹ, ən ɛɡwin kəd si naʊ ðət ðeɪ wɝ lɪŋk baɪ ə sɪlvɝ kɔɹd dʒʌs laɪk ðə wʌn ðət stɪl dʒɔɪn əɹ tə ðə wʊmən stændɪŋ oʊvɝ hɝ.

When she could see straight once more, the wind had died. A number of horses wandered loose, Bela and Elayne's mare among them, and some of the soldiers were cursing and picking themselves up off the ground. Liandrin was calmly brushing dust and leaves from her dress. Min knelt, supporting herself with her hands, groggily trying to rise further. The hook-nosed man stood over her, his hand dripping blood. Min's knife lay just out of her reach, the blade stained red along one side. Nynaeve and Elayne were nowhere to be seen, and Nynaeve's mare was gone, too. So were some of the soldiers, and one of the pairs of women. The other two were still there, and Egwene could see now that they were linked by a silver cord just like the one that still joined her to the woman standing over her.

ðət wʊmən wɑz ɹʌbɪŋ əɹ tʃik əz ʃi skwɑɾɪd bɪsaɪɾ ɛɡwin; ðəɹ wɑz ə bɹuz ɔlɹɛɾi kʌmɪŋ ʌp ɝaʊn əɹ lɛft aɪ. wɪð lɔŋ, dɑɹk hɛɹ ən bɪɡ bɹaʊn aɪz, ʃi wɑz pɹɪɾi, ən pɝhæps əz mʌtʃ əz tɛn jɪɹz oʊldɝ ðən nɪneɪiv. "jɔɹ fɝs lɛsən," ʃi sɛɾ ɛmfæɾɪkli. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ænəmɑsəɾi ɪn əɹ vɔɪs, bʌt wʌɾ ɔlmoʊst saʊndəd laɪk fɹɛnlinɪs. "aɪ wɪl nɑt pʌnɪʃ jə fɝðɝ ðɪs taɪm, sɪns aɪ ʃʊɾə bɪn ɑn ɡɑɹd wɪð ə nuli kɑt deɪmeɪn. noʊ ðɪs. jə ɑɹ ə deɪmeɪn, ə liʃt wʌn, ən aɪm ə sʌldəm, ə hoʊldɝ ə ðə liʃ. wən deɪmeɪn ən sʌldəm ɑɹ dʒɔɪnd, wʌtɛvɝ hɝt ðə sʌldəm filz, ðə deɪmeɪn filz twaɪs oʊvɝ. ivən tə dɛθ. soʊ jə mʌst ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðət jə meɪ nɛvɝ stʃɹaɪk əɾ ə sʌldəm ɪn ɛni weɪ, ən jə mʌs pɹətɛk jəɹ sʌldəm ivən mɔɹ ðən jɝsɛlf. aɪm ɹɛnə. haʊ ɑɹ jə kɔld?"

That woman was rubbing her cheek as she squatted beside Egwene; there was a bruise already coming up around her left eye. With long, dark hair and big brown eyes, she was pretty, and perhaps as much as ten years older than Nynaeve. "Your first lesson," she said emphatically. There was no animosity in her voice, but what almost sounded like friendliness. "I will not punish you further this time, since I should have been on guard with a newly caught damane. Know this. You are a damane, a Leashed One, and I am a sul'dam, a Holder of the Leash. When damane and sul'dam are joined, whatever hurt the sul'dam feels, the damane feels twice over. Even to death. So you must remember that you may never strike at a sul'dam in any way, and you must protect your sul'dam even more than yourself. I am Renna. How are you called?"

"aɪ æm nɑt . . . wʌt jə sɛd," ɛɡwin mʌɾɝd. ʃi pʊld ət ðə kɑlɝ əɡɛn; ɪt ɡeɪv noʊ mɔɹ ðən bɪfɔɹ. ʃi θɔɾ ə nɑkɪŋ ðə wʊmən daʊn ən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pɹaɪ ðə bɹeɪslət fɹəm əɹ ɹɪst, bʌt ɹɪdʒɛktɪɾ ɪt. ivən ɪf ðə soʊlʒɝz dɪd nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə stɑp əɹ - ən soʊ fɑɹ ðeɪ sim tə bi ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ əɹ ən ɹɛnə ɔltəɡɛðɝ - ʃi hæd ðə sɪŋkɪŋ filɪŋ ðə wʊmən wɑz tɛlɪŋ ðə tʃɹuθ. tʌtʃɪŋ əɹ lɛft aɪ bɹɔɾ ə wɪns; ɪt dɪd nɑt fil pʌfi, soʊ pɝhæps ʃi wɑz nɑɾ æktʃəli  ɡɹoʊɪŋ ə bɹuz tə mætʃ ɹɛnəz, bʌɾ ɪt stɪl hɝt. hɝ lɛft aɪ, ən ɹɛnəz lɛft aɪ. ʃi ɹeɪzd əɹ vɔɪs. "liɑnʒɹɪn sədaɪ? waɪ ɑɹ jə lɛɾɪŋ əm də ðɪs?" liɑnʒɹɪn dʌstɪɾ əɹ hænz təɡɛðɝ, nɛvɝ lʊkɪŋ ɪn əɹ dɝɛkʃən.

"I am not . . . what you said," Egwene muttered. She pulled at the collar again; it gave no more than before. She thought of knocking the woman down and trying to pry the bracelet from her wrist, but rejected it. Even if the soldiers did not try to stop her - and so far they seemed to be ignoring her and Renna altogether - she had the sinking feeling the woman was telling the truth. Touching her left eye brought a wince; it did not feel puffy, so perhaps she was not actually growing a bruise to match Renna's, but it still hurt. Her left eye, and Renna's left eye. She raised her voice. "Liandrin Sedai? Why are you letting them do this?" Liandrin dusted her hands together, never looking in her direction.

"ðə vɛɹi fɝs θɪŋ jə mʌs lɝn," ɹɛnə sɛd, "ɪz tə də ɪɡzækli əz jə ɑɹ toʊld, ən wɪθaʊt dɪleɪ."

"The very first thing you must learn," Renna said, "is to do exactly as you are told, and without delay."

ɛɡwin ɡæspt. sʌɾənli hɝ skɪn bɝn ən pɹɪkəld əz ɪf ʃi hæd ɹoʊld ɪn stɪŋɪŋ nɛɾəlz, fɹəm ðə soʊlz ə hɝ fit tə hɝ skælp. ʃi tɔst əɹ hɛɾ əz ðə bɝnɪŋ sɛnseɪʃən ɪnkɹist.

Egwene gasped. Suddenly her skin burned and prickled as if she had rolled in stinging nettles, from the soles of her feet to her scalp. She tossed her head as the burning sensation increased.

"mɛni sʌldəm," ɹɛnə wɛn ɑn ɪn ðəɾ ɔlmoʊs fɹɛnli toʊn, "du nɑt bɪliv deɪmeɪn ʃəd bi əlaʊd neɪmz, əɹ ət list oʊnli neɪmz ðeɪ ɑɹ ɡɪvən. bʌɾ aɪm ðə wʌn u tʊk ju, soʊ əl bi ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ ə jəɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ, ən əl əlaʊ jə tə kip jəɹ oʊn neɪm. ɪf jə də nɑt dɪspliz mi tu fɑɹ. aɪm maɪldli əpsɛt wɪð jə naʊ. dʒju ɹɪli wɪʃ tə kip ɑn əntɪl aɪm æŋɡɹi?"

"Many sul'dam," Renna went on in that almost friendly tone, "do not believe damane should be allowed names, or at least only names they are given. But I am the one who took you, so I will be in charge of your training, and I will allow you to keep your own name. If you do not displease me too far. I am mildly upset with you now. Do you really wish to keep on until I am angry?"

kwɪvɝɪŋ, ɛɡwin ɡɹɪɾɪd əɹ tiθ. hɝ neɪlz dʌɡ ɪndə hɝ pɑmz wɪð ði ɛfɝɾ ə nɑt skɹætʃɪŋ waɪldli. ɪɾiət! ɪts oʊnli jəɹ neɪm. "ɛɡwin," ʃi mænədʒ tə ɡɛɾ aʊt. "aɪ æm ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ." ɪnstənli ðə bɝnɪŋ ɪtʃ wɑz ɡɔn. ʃi lɛɾ aʊɾ ə lɔŋ, ənstɛɾi bɹɛθ.

Quivering, Egwene gritted her teeth. Her nails dug into her palms with the effort of not scratching wildly. Idiot! It's only your name. "Egwene," she managed to get out. "I am Egwene al'Vere." Instantly the burning itch was gone. She let out a long, unsteady breath.

"ɛɡwin," ɹɛnə sɛd. "ðæɾ ɪz ə ɡʊd neɪm." ən tə ɛɡwinz hɔɹɝ, ɹɛnə pæɾəd əɹ ɑn ðə hɛɾ əz ʃi wəɾ ə dɔɡ.

"Egwene," Renna said. "That is a good name." And to Egwene's horror, Renna patted her on the head as she would a dog.

ðæt, ʃi ɹilaɪzd, wɑz wʌt ʃi hæd dɪtɛktəɾ ɪn ðə wʊmənz vɔɪs - ə sɝɾən ɡʊd wɪl fəɹ ə dɔɡ ɪn tʃɹeɪnɪŋ, nɑt kwaɪt ðə fɹɛnlinɪs wʌn maɪɾ əv təwɔɹɾ ənʌðɝ hjumən biɪŋ.

That, she realized, was what she had detected in the woman's voice - a certain good will for a dog in training, not quite the friendliness one might have toward another human being.

ɹɛnə tʃʌkəld. "naʊ jə ɑɹ ivən æŋɡɹiɝ. ɪf jə ɪntɛn tə stʃɹaɪk ət mi əɡɛn, ɹɪmɛmbɝ tə meɪk ɪɾ ə smɔl bloʊ, fəɹ jəl fil ɪt twaɪs əz hɑɹɾ əz aɪ. də nɑɾ ətɛmp tə tʃænəl; ðət jəl nɛvɝ də wɪθaʊt maɪ ɪkspɹɛs kəmænd."

Renna chuckled. "Now you are even angrier. If you intend to strike at me again, remember to make it a small blow, for you will feel it twice as hard as I. Do not attempt to channel; that you will never do without my express command."

ɛɡwinz aɪ θɹɑbd. ʃi pʊʃt hɝsɛlf tə hɝ fiɾ ən tʃɹaɪd tə ɪɡnɔɹ ɹɛnə, əz mʌtʃ əz ɪt wɑz pɑsəbəl tə ɪɡnɔɹ sʌmwʌn u hɛld ə liʃ fæsən tə ə kɑlɝ ɝaʊn jəɹ nɛk. hɝ tʃiks bɝnd wən ði ʌðɝ wʊmən tʃʌkəld əɡɛn. ʃi wɑntəd tə ɡoʊ tə mɪn, bʌt ði əmaʊn ə liʃ ɹɛnə hæd lɛɾ aʊt wəd nɑt ɹitʃ ðət fɑɹ. ʃi kɔl sɔfli, "mɪn, ɑɹ jə ɔl ɹaɪt?"

Egwene's eye throbbed. She pushed herself to her feet and tried to ignore Renna, as much as it was possible to ignore someone who held a leash fastened to a collar around your neck. Her cheeks burned when the other woman chuckled again. She wanted to go to Min, but the amount of leash Renna had let out would not reach that far. She called softly, "Min, are you all right?"

sɪɾɪŋ sloʊli bæk ɑn əɹ hilz, mɪn nɑɾəd, ðən pʊɾ ə hæn tə hɝ hɛɾ əz ɪf ʃi wɪʃt ʃi hæd nɑt muvd ɪt.

Sitting slowly back on her heels, Min nodded, then put a hand to her head as if she wished she had not moved it.

dʒæɡd laɪtnɪŋ kɹækəld əkɹɔs ðə klɪɹ skaɪ, ðən stʃɹʌk əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz səm dɪstəns ɔf. ɛɡwin dʒʌmpt, ən sʌɾənli smaɪld. nɪneɪiv wɑz stɪl fɹi, ən ɪleɪn. ɪf ɛniwʌn kəd fɹi hɝ ən mɪn, nɪneɪiv kʊd. hɝ smaɪl feɪɾəd ɪndə ə ɡlɛɹ fəɹ liɑnʒɹɪn. fəɹ wʌtɛvɝ ðə ɹizən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd bɪtʃɹeɪd ðɛm, ðəɹ wəd bi ə ɹɛkənɪŋ. sʌmdeɪ. sʌmhaʊ. ðə ɡlɛɹ dɪd noʊ ɡʊd; liɑnʒɹɪn dɪd nɑt lʊk əweɪ fɹəm ðə pɑlɑnkwɪn.

Jagged lightning crackled across the clear sky, then struck among the trees some distance off. Egwene jumped, and suddenly smiled. Nynaeve was still free, and Elayne. If anyone could free her and Min, Nynaeve could. Her smile faded into a glare for Liandrin. For whatever the reason the Aes Sedai had betrayed them, there would be a reckoning. Someday. Somehow. The glare did no good; Liandrin did not look away from the palanquin.

ðə bɛɹ-tʃɛstəd mɛn nɛlt, loʊɝɪŋ ðə pɑlɑnkwɪn tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ən sjuɹɔθ stɛp daʊn, kɛɹfəli ɝeɪnʒɪŋ əɹ ɹoʊb, ðən pɪkt əɹ weɪ tə liɑnʒɹɪn ɑn sɑft-slɪpɝd fit. ðə tu wɪmən wɝ mʌtʃ ʌv ə saɪz. bɹaʊn aɪz stɛɹd lɛvəli ɪndə blæk.

The bare-chested men knelt, lowering the palanquin to the ground, and Suroth stepped down, carefully arranging her robe, then picked her way to Liandrin on soft-slippered feet. The two women were much of a size. Brown eyes stared levelly into black.

"ju wɝ tə bɹɪŋ mi tu," sjuɹɔθ sɛd. "ɪnstɛd, aɪ hæv oʊnli wʌn, waɪl tu ɹʌn lus, wʌn ə ðɛm mɔɹ paʊɝfəl baɪ fɑɹ ðən aɪ hæd bɪn lɛd tə bɪliv. ʃɪl ətʃɹækt ɛvɹi pətʃɹoʊl ʌv aʊɝz wɪðɪn tu liɡz."

"You were to bring me two," Suroth said. "Instead, I have only one, while two run loose, one of them more powerful by far than I had been led to believe. She will attract every patrol of ours within two leagues."

"aɪ bɹɔt jə θɹi," liɑnʒɹɪn sɛd kɑmli. "ɪf jə kænɑt mænədʒ tə hoʊl ðɛm, pɝhæps əɹ mæstɝ ʃəd faɪn ənʌðɝ əmʌŋ jə tə sɝv hɪm. jə teɪk fɹaɪɾ ət tʃɹaɪfəlz. ɪf pətʃɹoʊlz kʌm, kɪl ðɛm."

"I brought you three," Liandrin said calmly. "If you cannot manage to hold them, perhaps our master should find another among you to serve him. You take fright at trifles. If patrols come, kill them."

laɪtnɪŋ flæʃt əɡɛn ɪn ðə nɪɹ dɪstəns, ən moʊməns leɪɾɝ sʌmθɪŋ ɹɔɹd laɪk θʌndɝ nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm wɛɹ ɪt stʃɹʌk; ə klaʊɾ ə dʌst ɹoʊz ɪndə ði ɛɹ. niðɝ liɑnʒɹɪn nɔɹ sjuɹɔθ tʊk ɛni noʊɾəs.

Lightning flashed again in the near distance, and moments later something roared like thunder not far from where it struck; a cloud of dust rose into the air. Neither Liandrin nor Suroth took any notice.

"aɪ kəd stɪl ɹɪtɝn tə fɑlm wɪð tu nu deɪmeɪn," sjuɹɔθ sɛd. "ɪt ɡɹivz mi tə əlaʊ ən . . . ɛɛs sədaɪ" - ʃi twɪstəd ðə wɝdz laɪk ə kɝs - "tə wɔk fɹi."

"I could still return to Falme with two new damane," Suroth said. "It grieves me to allow an . . . Aes Sedai" - she twisted the words like a curse - "to walk free."

liɑnʒɹɪnz feɪs dɪd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ, bʌɾ ɛɡwin sɔ ə nɪmbəs əbɹʌpli ɡloʊ ɝaʊn hɝ.

Liandrin's face did not change, but Egwene saw a nimbus abruptly glow around her.

"bɪwɛɹ, haɪ leɪɾi," ɹɛnə kɔld. "ʃi stænz ɹɛɾi!"

"Beware, High Lady," Renna called. "She stands ready!"

ðəɹ wɑz ə stɝ əmʌŋ ðə soʊlʒɝz, ə ɹitʃɪŋ fəɹ sɔɹdz ən lænsɪz, bʌt sjuɹɔθ oʊnli stipəld əɹ hænz, smaɪlɪŋ ət liɑnʒɹɪn oʊvɝ əɹ lɔŋ neɪlz. "ju wɪl meɪk noʊ muv əɡɛns mi, liɑnʒɹɪn. əɹ mæstɝ wəd dɪsəpɹuv, əz aɪm ʃʊɹli niɾəd hɪɹ mɔɹ ðən ju, ən jə fɪɹ ɪm mɔɹ ðən jə fɪɹ biɪŋ meɪd deɪmeɪn."

There was a stir among the soldiers, a reaching for swords and lances, but Suroth only steepled her hands, smiling at Liandrin over her long nails. "You will make no move against me, Liandrin. Our master would disapprove, as I am surely needed here more than you, and you fear him more than you fear being made damane."

liɑnʒɹɪn smaɪld, ðoʊ waɪt spɑts mɑɹkt əɹ tʃiks wɪð æŋɡɝ. "æn ju, sjuɹɔθ, fɪɹ ɪm mɔɹ ðən jə fɪɹ mi bɝnɪŋ jə tə ə sɪndɝ wɛɹ jə stænd."

Liandrin smiled, though white spots marked her cheeks with anger. "And you, Suroth, fear him more than you fear me burning you to a cinder where you stand."

"dʒʌst soʊ. wi boʊθ fɪɹ hɪm. jɛɾ ivən əɹ mæstɝz nidz wɪl tʃeɪnʒ wɪð taɪm. ɔl mɛɹəθdəmeɪn wɪl bi liʃt ɪvɛntʃəwəli. pɝhæps əl bi ðə wʌn u pleɪsəz ðə kɑlɝ ɝaʊn jəɹ lʌvli θɹoʊt."

"Just so. We both fear him. Yet even our master's needs will change with time. All marath'damane will be leashed eventually. Perhaps I will be the one who places the collar around your lovely throat."

"æz jə seɪ, sjuɹɔθ. əɹ mæstɝz nidz wɪl tʃeɪnʒ. əl ɹimaɪn jə ʌv ɪɾ ɑn ðə deɪ wən jə nil tə mi."

"As you say, Suroth. Our master's needs will change. I will remind you of it on the day when you kneel to me."

ə tɔl lɛðɝlif pɝhæps ə maɪl əweɪ sʌɾənli bɪkeɪm ə ɹɔɹɪŋ tɔɹtʃ.

A tall leatherleaf perhaps a mile away suddenly became a roaring torch.

"ðɪs ɡɹoʊz taɪɝsəm," sjuɹɔθ sɛd. "ɛlbɑɹ, ɹikɔl ðɛm." ðə hʊk-noʊz mæn pɹədust ə hɔɹn noʊ bɪɡɝ ðən ɪz fɪst; ɪt meɪɾ ə hɔɹs, pɪɹsɪŋ kɹaɪ.

"This grows tiresome," Suroth said. "Elbar, recall them." The hook-nosed man produced a horn no bigger than his fist; it made a hoarse, piercing cry.

"ju mʌs faɪn ðə wʊmən nɪneɪiv," liɑnʒɹɪn sɛd ʃɑɹpli. "ɪleɪn ɪz ə noʊ ɪmpɔɹɾəns, bʌt boʊθ ðə wʊmən ən ðɪs ɡɝl hɪɹ mʌs bi teɪkən wɪð jə ɑn jəɹ ʃɪps wən jə seɪl."

"You must find the woman Nynaeve," Liandrin said sharply. "Elayne is of no importance, but both the woman and this girl here must be taken with you on your ships when you sail."

"aɪ noʊ vɛɹi wɛl wʌɾ əz bɪn kəmændəd, mɛɹəθdəmeɪn, ðoʊ aɪ wəd ɡɪv mʌtʃ tə noʊ waɪ."

"I know very well what has been commanded, marath'damane, though I would give much to know why."

"haʊɛvɝ mʌtʃ jə wɝ toʊld, tʃaɪld," liɑnʒɹɪn snɪɹd, "ðæɾ ɪz haʊ mʌtʃ jə ɑɹ əlaʊd tə noʊ. ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðət jə sɝv ən oʊbeɪ. ðiz tu mʌs bi ɹimuv tə ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən ən kɛp ðɛɹ."

"However much you were told, child," Liandrin sneered, "that is how much you are allowed to know. Remember that you serve and obey. These two must be removed to the other side of the Aryth Ocean and kept there."

sjuɹɔθ snɪft. "aɪ wɪl nɑt ɹɪmeɪn hɪɹ tə faɪn ðɪs nɪneɪiv. maɪ jusfəlnəs tə əɹ mæstɝ wɪl bi əɾ ən ɛn ɪf tʃɹɑk hænz mi oʊvɝ tə ðə sikɝz fəɹ tʃɹuθ." liɑnʒɹɪn oʊpən əɹ maʊθ æŋɡɹəli, bʌt sjuɹɔθ ɹəfjuz tə əlaʊ hɝ ə wɝd. "ðə wʊmən wɪl nɑt ɹɪmeɪn fɹi fəɹ lɔŋ. niðɝ ə ðɛm wɪl. wən wi seɪl əɡɛn, wɪl teɪk wɪð əs ɛvɹi wʊmən ɑn ðɪs mɪzɝəbəl spɪɾ ə læn u kən tʃænəl ivən slaɪtli, liʃt ən kɑlɝd. ɪf jə wɪʃ tə ɹɪmeɪn ən sɝtʃ fəɹ hɝ, də soʊ. pətʃɹoʊlz wɪl bi hɪɹ sun, θɪŋkɪŋ tə ɛnɡeɪdʒ ðə ɹæbəl ðət stɪl haɪdz ɪn ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd. səm pətʃɹoʊlz teɪk deɪmeɪn wɪð ðɛm, ən ðəl nɑt kɛɹ wʌt mæstɝ jə sɝv. ʃəd jə sɝvaɪv ði ɪnkaʊntɝ, ðə liʃ ən kɑlɝ wɪl titʃ jə ə nu laɪf, ən aɪ də nɑt bɪliv əɹ mæstɝ wɪl tʃɹʌbəl tə dɪlɪvɝ wʌn fulɪʃ ɪnʌf tə lɛt hɝsɛlf bi teɪkən."

Suroth sniffed. "I will not remain here to find this Nynaeve. My usefulness to our master will be at an end if Turak hands me over to the Seekers for Truth." Liandrin opened her mouth angrily, but Suroth refused to allow her a word. "The woman will not remain free for long. Neither of them will. When we sail again, we will take with us every woman on this miserable spit of land who can channel even slightly, leashed and collared. If you wish to remain and search for her, do so. Patrols will be here soon, thinking to engage the rabble that still hides in the countryside. Some patrols take damane with them, and they will not care what master you serve. Should you survive the encounter, the leash and collar will teach you a new life, and I do not believe our master will trouble to deliver one foolish enough to let herself be taken."

"ɪf iðɝ ɪz əlaʊd tə ɹɪmeɪn hɪɹ," liɑnʒɹɪn sɛd taɪtli, "aʊɝ mæstɝ wɪl tʃɹʌbəl hɪmsɛlf wɪð ju, sjuɹɔθ. teɪk əm boʊθ, əɹ peɪ ðə pɹaɪs." ʃi stʃɹoʊd tə ðə weɪɡeɪt, klʌtʃɪŋ ðə ɹeɪnz ə hɝ mɛɹ. sun ɪt wɑz kloʊzɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɝ.

"If either is allowed to remain here," Liandrin said tightly, "our master will trouble himself with you, Suroth. Take them both, or pay the price." She strode to the Waygate, clutching the reins of her mare. Soon it was closing behind her.

ðə soʊlʒɝz u hæd ɡɔn æftɝ nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn keɪm ɡæləpɪŋ bæk wɪð ðə tu wɪmən lɪŋk baɪ liʃ, kɑlɝ, ən bɹeɪslət, ðə deɪmeɪn ən ðə sʌldəm ɹaɪɾɪŋ saɪd baɪ saɪd. θɹi mɛn lɛd hɔɹsəz wɪð bɑɾiz əkɹɔs ðə sæɾəlz. ɛɡwin fɛlt ə sɝdʒ ə hoʊp wən ʃi ɹilaɪz ðə bɑɾiz ɔl wɔɹ ɑɹmɝ. ðeɪ hæd nɑt kɑt nɪneɪiv əɹ ɪleɪn, iðɝ wʌn.

The soldiers who had gone after Nynaeve and Elayne came galloping back with the two women linked by leash, collar, and bracelet, the damane and the sul'dam riding side by side. Three men led horses with bodies across the saddles. Egwene felt a surge of hope when she realized the bodies all wore armor. They had not caught Nynaeve or Elayne, either one.

mɪn stɑɹɾəd tə ɹaɪz tə hɝ fit, bʌt ðə hʊk-noʊz mæn plæntəɾ ə but bɪtwin əɹ ʃoʊldɝ bleɪdz ən dʒɹoʊv əɹ tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ɡæspɪŋ fəɹ bɹɛθ, ʃi twɪtʃt ðəɹ wikli. "aɪ bɛɡ pɝmɪʃən tə spik, haɪ leɪɾi," hi sɛd. sjuɹɔθ meɪɾ ə smɔl moʊʃən wɪð əɹ hænd, ən i wɛn ɑn. "ðɪs pɛzən kʌt mi, haɪ leɪɾi. ɪf ðə haɪ leɪɾi hæz noʊ jus fəɹ əɹ . . . ?" sjuɹɔθ moʊʃən slaɪtli əɡɛn, ɔlɹɛɾi tɝnɪŋ əweɪ, ən i ɹitʃt oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ fəɹ ðə hɪlt ə hɪz sɔɹd.

Min started to rise to her feet, but the hook-nosed man planted a boot between her shoulder blades and drove her to the ground. Gasping for breath, she twitched there weakly. "I beg permission to speak, High Lady," he said. Suroth made a small motion with her hand, and he went on. "This peasant cut me, High Lady. If the High Lady has no use for her . . . ?" Suroth motioned slightly again, already turning away, and he reached over his shoulder for the hilt of his sword.

"noʊ!" ɛɡwin ʃaʊɾəd. ʃi hɝd ɹɛnə kɝs sɔfli, ən sʌɾənli ðə bɝnɪŋ ɪtʃ kʌvɝɾ əɹ skɪn əɡɛn, wɝs ðən bɪfɔɹ, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt stɑp. "pliz! haɪ leɪɾi, pliz! ʃiz maɪ fɹɛnd!" peɪn sətʃ əz ʃi hæd nɛvɝ noʊn ɹækt əɹ θɹu ðə bɝnɪŋ. ɛvɹi mʌsəl nɑɾɪd ən kɹæmpt; ʃi pɪtʃt ɑn əɹ feɪs ɪn ðə dɝt, mulɪŋ, bʌt ʃi kəd stɪl si ɛlbɑɹz hɛvi, kɝv bleɪd kʌm fɹi ʌv ɪts ʃiθ, si hɪm ɹeɪz ɪt wɪð boʊθ hænz. "pliz! oʊ, mɪn!"

"No!" Egwene shouted. She heard Renna curse softly, and suddenly the burning itch covered her skin again, worse than before, but she did not stop. "Please! High Lady, please! She is my friend!" Pain such as she had never known wracked her through the burning. Every muscle knotted and cramped; she pitched on her face in the dirt, mewling, but she could still see Elbar's heavy, curved blade come free of its sheath, see him raise it with both hands. "Please! Oh, Min!"

əbɹʌpli, ðə peɪn wɑz ɡɔn əz ɪf ɪt hæd nɛvɝ bɪn; oʊnli ðə mɛmɹi ɹɪmeɪnd. sjuɹɔθs blu vɛlvət slɪpɝz, dɝt-steɪnd naʊ, əpɪɹɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ feɪs, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz əɾ ɛlbɑɹ ðət ʃi stɛɹd. hi stʊd ðəɹ wɪð ɪz sɔɹɾ oʊvɝ ɪz hɛɾ ən ɔl ɪz weɪɾ ɑn ðə fʊɾ ɑn mɪnz bæk . . . ən i dɪd nɑt muv.

Abruptly, the pain was gone as if it had never been; only the memory remained. Suroth's blue velvet slippers, dirt-stained now, appeared in front of her face, but it was at Elbar that she stared. He stood there with his sword over his head and all his weight on the foot on Min's back . . . and he did not move.

"ðɪs pɛzən ɪz jəɹ fɹɛnd?" sjuɹɔθ sɛd.

"This peasant is your friend?" Suroth said.

ɛɡwin stɑɹɾəd tə ɹaɪz, bʌɾ əɾ ə sɝpɹaɪzd ɑɹtʃɪŋ ə sjuɹɔθs aɪbɹaʊ, ʃi ɹɪmeɪn laɪɪŋ wɛɹ ʃi wɑz ən oʊnli ɹeɪzd əɹ hɛd. ʃi hæd tə seɪv mɪn. ɪf ɪt minz ɡɹɔvəlɪŋ. . . . ʃi pɑɹɾəd əɹ lɪps ən hoʊpt əɹ ɡɹɪɾɪd tiθ wəd pæs fəɹ ə smaɪl. "jɛs, haɪ leɪɾi."

Egwene started to rise, but at a surprised arching of Suroth's eyebrow, she remained lying where she was and only raised her head. She had to save Min. If it means groveling. . . . She parted her lips and hoped her gritted teeth would pass for a smile. "Yes, High Lady."

"æn ɪf aɪ spɛɹ hɝ, ɪf aɪ əlaʊ hɝ tə vɪzət jə əkeɪʒənəli, jəl wɝk hɑɹɾ ən lɝn əz jə ɑɹ tɔt?"

"And if I spare her, if I allow her to visit you occasionally, you will work hard and learn as you are taught?"

"aɪ wɪl, haɪ leɪɾi." ʃi wʊɾə pɹɑməs mʌtʃ mɔɹ tə kip ðət sɔɹd fɹəm splɪɾɪŋ mɪnz skʌl. əl ivən kip ɪt, ʃi θɔt saʊɝli, əz lɔŋ əz aɪ hæv tə.

"I will, High Lady." She would have promised much more to keep that sword from splitting Min's skull. I'll even keep it, she thought sourly, as long as I have to.

"pʊt ðə ɡɝl ɑn əɹ hɔɹs, ɛlbɑɹ," sjuɹɔθ sɛd. "taɪ hɝ ɑn, ɪf ʃi kænɑt sɪɾ əɹ sæɾəl. ɪf ðɪs deɪmeɪn pɹuvz ə dɪsəpɔɪnmənt, pɝhæps ðən əl lɛt juv ðə hɛɾ ə ðə ɡɝl." ʃi wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi muvɪŋ təwɔɹɾ əɹ pɑlɑnkwɪn.

"Put the girl on her horse, Elbar," Suroth said. "Tie her on, if she cannot sit her saddle. If this damane proves a disappointment, perhaps then I will let you have the head of the girl." She was already moving toward her palanquin.

ɹɛnə pʊld ɛɡwin ɹʌfli tə hɝ fiɾ ən pʊʃt əɹ təwɔɹd bɛlə, bʌɾ ɛɡwin hæɾ aɪz oʊnli fəɹ mɪn. ɛlbɑɹ wɑz noʊ dʒɛnlɝ wɪð mɪn ðən ɹɛnə wɪð hɝ, bʌt ʃi θɔt mɪn wɑz ɔl ɹaɪt. ət lis mɪn ʃɹʌɡd ɔf ɛlbɑɹz ətɛmp tə taɪ hɝ əkɹɔs əɹ sæɾəl ən klaɪmd ɑntu hɝ ɡɛldɪŋ wɪð oʊnli ə lɪɾəl hɛlp.

Renna pulled Egwene roughly to her feet and pushed her toward Bela, but Egwene had eyes only for Min. Elbar was no gentler with Min than Renna with her, but she thought Min was all right. At least Min shrugged off Elbar's attempt to tie her across her saddle and climbed onto her gelding with only a little help.

ði ɑd pɑɹɾi stɑɹɾəd ɔf, wɛstwɝd, wɪð sjuɹɔθ liɾɪŋ ən ɛlbɑɹ slaɪtli tə ðə ɹɪɹ ə hɝ pɑlɑnkwɪn, bʌt kloʊs ɪnʌf tə hiɾ ɛni sʌmənz ɪmiɾiətli. ɹɛnə ən ɛɡwin ɹoʊɾ ət ðə bæk wɪð mɪn, ən ði ʌðɝ sʌldəm ən deɪmeɪn, bɪhaɪn ðə soʊlʒɝz. ðə wʊmən u hæɾ əpɛɹənli mɛn tə kɑlɝ nɪneɪiv fɑndəl ðə kɔɪl sɪlvɝ liʃ ʃi stɪl kæɹiɾ ən lʊkt æŋɡɹi. spɑɹs fɔɹəs kʌvɝd ðə ɹoʊlɪŋ lænd, ən ðə smoʊk ə ðə bɝnɪŋ lɛðɝlif wɑz sun oʊnli ə smʌdʒ ɪn ðə skaɪ bɪhaɪn ðɛm.

The odd party started off, westward, with Suroth leading and Elbar slightly to the rear of her palanquin, but close enough to heed any summons immediately. Renna and Egwene rode at the back with Min, and the other sul'dam and damane, behind the soldiers. The woman who had apparently meant to collar Nynaeve fondled the coiled silver leash she still carried and looked angry. Sparse forest covered the rolling land, and the smoke of the burning leatherleaf was soon only a smudge in the sky behind them.

"ju wɝ ɑnɝd," ɹɛnə sɛɾ æftɝ ə taɪm, "hævɪŋ ðə haɪ leɪɾi spik tə ju. ənʌðɝ taɪm, aɪ wəd lɛt jə wɛɹ ə ɹɪbən tə mɑɹk ði ɑnɝ. bʌt sɪns jə bɹɔɾ əɹ ətɛnʃən ɑn jɝsɛlf. . . ."

"You were honored," Renna said after a time, "having the High Lady speak to you. Another time, I would let you wear a ribbon to mark the honor. But since you brought her attention on yourself. . . ."

ɛɡwin kɹaɪɾ aʊɾ əz ə swɪtʃ sim tə læʃ əkɹɔs əɹ bæk, ðən ənʌðɝ əkɹɔs əɹ lɛɡ, hɝ ɑɹm. fɹəm ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən ðeɪ sim tə kʌm; ʃi nu ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə blɑk, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt hɛlp θɹoʊɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz əbaʊɾ əz ɪf tə stɑp ðə bloʊz. ʃi bɪɾ əɹ lɪp tə staɪfəl əɹ moʊnz, bʌt tɪɹz stɪl ɹoʊl daʊn əɹ tʃiks. bɛlə wɪniɾ ən dænst, bʌt ɹɛnəz ɡɹɪp ɑn ðə sɪlvɝ liʃ kɛpt əɹ fɹəm kæɹiɪŋ ɛɡwin əweɪ. nʌn ə ðə soʊlʒɝz ivən lʊk bæk.

Egwene cried out as a switch seemed to lash across her back, then another across her leg, her arm. From every direction they seemed to come; she knew there was nothing to block, but she could not help throwing her arms about as if to stop the blows. She bit her lip to stifle her moans, but tears still rolled down her cheeks. Bela whinnied and danced, but Renna's grip on the silver leash kept her from carrying Egwene away. None of the soldiers even looked back.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ tə hɝ?" mɪn ʃaʊɾəd. "ɛɡwin? stɑp ɪt!"

"What are you doing to her?" Min shouted. "Egwene? Stop it!"

"ju lɪv ɑn sʌfɝæns . . . mɪn, ɪz ɪt?" ɹɛnə sɛd maɪldli. "lɛt ðɪs bi ə lɛsən fəɹ jə əz wɛl. soʊ lɔŋ əz jə tʃɹaɪ tə ɪntɝfɪɹ, ɪɾəl nɑt stɑp."

"You live on sufferance . . . Min, is it?" Renna said mildly. "Let this be a lesson for you as well. So long as you try to interfere, it will not stop."

mɪn ɹeɪzd ə fɪst, ðən lɛɾ ɪt fɔl. "aɪ woʊn ɪntɝfɪɹ. oʊnli, pliz, stɑp ɪt. ɛɡwin, aɪm sɑɹi."

Min raised a fist, then let it fall. "I won't interfere. Only, please, stop it. Egwene, I'm sorry."

ði ənsin bloʊz wɛn ɑn fəɹ ə fju moʊməns mɔɹ, əz ɪf tə ʃoʊ mɪn əɹ ɪntɝvɛntʃən hæd dʌn nʌθɪŋ, ðən sist, bʌɾ ɛɡwin kəd nɑt stɑp ʃʌɾɝɪŋ. ðə peɪn dɪd nɑt ɡoʊ əweɪ ðɪs taɪm. ʃi pʊʃt bæk ðə sliv ə hɝ dʒɹɛs, θɪŋkɪŋ tə si wɛlz; hɝ skɪn wɑz ənmɑɹkt, bʌt ðə fil ə ðɛm wɑz stɪl ðɛɹ. ʃi swɑloʊd. "ɪt wɑz nɑt jəɹ fɔlt, mɪn." bɛlə tɔst əɹ hɛd, aɪz ɹoʊlɪŋ, ən ɛɡwin pæɾəd ðə mɛɹz ʃæɡi nɛk. "ɪt wɑzn jʊɹz, iðɝ."

The unseen blows went on for a few moments more, as if to show Min her intervention had done nothing, then ceased, but Egwene could not stop shuddering. The pain did not go away this time. She pushed back the sleeve of her dress, thinking to see weals; her skin was unmarked, but the feel of them was still there. She swallowed. "It was not your fault, Min." Bela tossed her head, eyes rolling, and Egwene patted the mare's shaggy neck. "It wasn't yours, either."

"ɪt wɑz jəɹ fɔlt, ɛɡwin," ɹɛnə sɛd. ʃi saʊndəd soʊ peɪʃənt, dilɪŋ soʊ kaɪnli wɪð sʌmwʌn u wɑz tu dɛns tə si ðə ɹaɪt, ðəɾ ɛɡwin wɑntəd tə skɹim. "wɛn ə deɪmeɪn ɪz pʌnɪʃt, ɪts ɔlweɪz əɹ fɔlt, ivən ɪf ʃi dʌz nɑt noʊ waɪ. ə deɪmeɪn mʌst æntɪsəpeɪt wʌɾ əɹ sʌldəm wɑns. bʌt ðɪs taɪm, jə də noʊ waɪ. deɪmeɪn ɑɹ laɪk fɝnɪtʃɝ, əɹ tulz, ɔlweɪz ðəɹ ɹɛɾi tə bi juzd, bʌt nɛvɝ pʊʃɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz fɔɹwɝd fəɹ ətɛnʃən. ɪspɛʃli nɑt fəɹ ði ətɛnʃən ʌv wʌn ə ðə blʌd."

"It was your fault, Egwene," Renna said. She sounded so patient, dealing so kindly with someone who was too dense to see the right, that Egwene wanted to scream. "When a damane is punished, it is always her fault, even if she does not know why. A damane must anticipate what her sul'dam wants. But this time, you do know why. Damane are like furniture, or tools, always there ready to be used, but never pushing themselves forward for attention. Especially not for the attention of one of the Blood."

ɛɡwin bɪɾ əɹ lɪp əntɪl ʃi teɪstəd blʌd. ðɪs ɪz ə naɪtmɛɹ. ɪt kæn bi ɹil. waɪ dɪd liɑnʒɹɪn də ðɪs? waɪ ɪz ðɪs hæpənɪŋ? "meɪ . . . meɪ aɪ æsk ə kwɛstʃən?"

Egwene bit her lip until she tasted blood. This is a nightmare. It can't be real. Why did Liandrin do this? Why is this happening? "May . . . may I ask a question?"

"ʌv mi, jə meɪ." ɹɛnə smaɪld.
