"mɛni sʌldəm wɪl wɛɹ jəɹ bɹeɪsləɾ oʊvɝ ðə jɪɹz - ðəɹ ɑɹ ɔlweɪz mɛni mɔɹ sʌldəm ðən deɪmeɪn - ən səm wəɾ əv jəɹ haɪɾ ɪn stʃɹɪps ɪf jə tʊk jəɹ aɪz ɔf ðə flɔɹ əɹ oʊpən jəɹ maʊθ wɪθaʊt pɝmɪʃən, bʌɾ aɪ si noʊ ɹizən nɑt tə lɛt jə spik, soʊ lɔŋ əz jə ɑɹ kɛɹfəl ɪn wʌt jə seɪ." wʌn ə ði ʌðɝ sʌldəm snɔɹɾɪd laʊdli; ʃi wɑz lɪŋk tə ə pɹɪɾi, dɑɹk-hɛɹd wʊmən ɪn əɹ mɪɾəl jɪɹz u kɛpt əɹ aɪz ɑn əɹ hænz.

"Of me, you may." Renna smiled. "Many sul'dam will wear your bracelet over the years - there are always many more sul'dam than damane - and some would have your hide in strips if you took your eyes off the floor or opened your mouth without permission, but I see no reason not to let you speak, so long as you are careful in what you say." One of the other sul'dam snorted loudly; she was linked to a pretty, dark-haired woman in her middle years who kept her eyes on her hands.

"liɑnʒɹɪn" - ɛɡwin wəd nɑt ɡɪv əɹ ði ɑnɝɪfɪk, nɑɾ ɛvɝ əɡɛn - "æn ðə haɪ leɪɾi spoʊk ʌv ə mæstɝ ðeɪ boʊθ sɝv." ðə θɔt keɪm ɪndə hɝ hɛɾ ʌv ə mæn wɪð ɔlmoʊs hil bɝnz mɑɹɪŋ ɪz feɪs, ən aɪz ən maʊθ ðət səmtaɪmz tɝn tə faɪɝ, bʌɾ ivən ɪf i wɑz oʊnli ə fɪɡjɝ ɪn əɹ dʒɹimz ðət sim tu hɔɹəbəl tə kɑntəmpleɪt. "hu ɪz hi? wʌt dʌz i wɑnt wɪð mi ən - ən mɪn?" ʃi nu ɪt wɑz sɪli tə əvɔɪd neɪmɪŋ nɪneɪiv - ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ɛni ʌv ðiz pipəl wəd fɝɡɛɾ əɹ dʒʌs kəz əɹ neɪm wɑz nɑt mɛnʃənd, ɪspɛʃli ðə blu-aɪd sʌldəm stʃɹoʊkɪŋ əɹ ɛmpti liʃ - bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ði oʊnli weɪ ʃi kəd θɪŋk ə faɪɾɪŋ bæk ət ðə moʊmənt.

"Liandrin" - Egwene would not give her the honorific, not ever again - "and the High Lady spoke of a master they both serve." The thought came into her head of a man with almost healed burns marring his face, and eyes and mouth that sometimes turned to fire, but even if he was only a figure in her dreams that seemed too horrible to contemplate. "Who is he? What does he want with me and - and Min?" She knew it was silly to avoid naming Nynaeve - she did not think any of these people would forget her just because her name was not mentioned, especially the blue-eyed sul'dam stroking her empty leash - but it was the only way she could think of fighting back at the moment.

"ði əfɛɹz ə ðə blʌd," ɹɛnə sɛd, "ɑɹ nɑt fəɹ mi tə teɪk noʊɾəs ʌv, ən sɝɾənli nɑt fəɹ ju. ðə haɪ leɪɾi wɪl tɛl mi wʌt ʃi wɪʃɪz mi tə noʊ, ən əl tɛl jə wʌɾ aɪ wɪʃ jə tə noʊ. ɛniθɪŋ ɛls ðət jə hɪɹ əɹ si mʌs bi tə jə əz ɪf ɪt nɛvɝ wɑz sɛd, əz ɪf ɪt nɛvɝ hæpənd. ðɪs weɪ laɪz seɪfti, moʊst ɪspɛʃli fəɹ ə deɪmeɪn. deɪmeɪn ɑɹ tu væljəbəl tə bi kɪld aʊɾ ə hænd, bʌt jə maɪt faɪn jɝsɛlf nɑɾ oʊnli saʊnli pʌnɪʃt, bʌɾ əbsɛn ə tʌŋ tə spik əɹ hænz tə ɹaɪt. deɪmeɪn kən də wʌt ðeɪ mʌst wɪθaʊt ðiz θɪŋz."

"The affairs of the Blood," Renna said, "are not for me to take notice of, and certainly not for you. The High Lady will tell me what she wishes me to know, and I will tell you what I wish you to know. Anything else that you hear or see must be to you as if it never was said, as if it never happened. This way lies safety, most especially for a damane. Damane are too valuable to be killed out of hand, but you might find yourself not only soundly punished, but absent a tongue to speak or hands to write. Damane can do what they must without these things."

ɛɡwin ʃɪvɝd, ðoʊ ði ɛɹ wɑz nɑt vɛɹi koʊld. pʊlɪŋ əɹ kloʊk ʌp ɑntu hɝ ʃoʊldɝz, hɝ hæn bɹʌʃt ðə liʃ, ən ʃi dʒɝkt əɾ ɪt fɪtfəli. "ðɪs ɪz ə hɔɹəbəl θɪŋ. haʊ kən jə də ðɪs tə ɛniwʌn? wʌt dɪziz maɪn ɛvɝ θɔɾ ʌv ɪt?"

Egwene shivered, though the air was not very cold. Pulling her cloak up onto her shoulders, her hand brushed the leash, and she jerked at it fitfully. "This is a horrible thing. How can you do this to anyone? What diseased mind ever thought of it?"

ðə blu-aɪd sʌldəm wɪð ði ɛmpti liʃ ɡɹaʊld, "ðɪs wʌn kəd də wɪθaʊɾ əɹ tʌŋ ɔlɹɛɾi, ɹɛnə."

The blue-eyed sul'dam with the empty leash growled, "This one could do without her tongue already, Renna."

ɹɛnə oʊnli smaɪl peɪʃənli. "haʊ ɪz ɪt hɔɹəbəl? kəd wi əlaʊ ɛniwʌn tə ɹʌn lus u kən də wʌɾ ə deɪmeɪn kæn? səmtaɪmz mɛn ɑɹ bɔɹn u wəd bi mɛɹəθdəmeɪn ɪf ðeɪ wɝ wɪmən - ɪts soʊ hɪɹ ɔlsoʊ, aɪ hæv hɝd - ən ðeɪ mʌs bi kɪld, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt ðə wɪmən də nɑt ɡoʊ mæd. bɛɾɝ fəɹ əm tə bɪkʌm deɪmeɪn ðən meɪk tʃɹʌbəl kəntɛndɪŋ fəɹ paʊɝ. əz fəɹ ðə maɪn ðət fɝs θɔɾ ə ði æɾəm, ɪt wɑz ðə maɪn ʌv ə wʊmən u kɔl hɝsɛlf ɛɛs sədaɪ."

Renna only smiled patiently. "How is it horrible? Could we allow anyone to run loose who can do what a damane can? Sometimes men are born who would be marath'damane if they were women - it is so here also, I have heard - and they must be killed, of course, but the women do not go mad. Better for them to become damane than make trouble contending for power. As for the mind that first thought of the a'dam, it was the mind of a woman who called herself Aes Sedai."

ɛɡwin nu ɪnkɹədulɪɾi mʌs bi peɪntɪŋ əɹ feɪs, kəz ɹɛnə læft oʊpənli. "wɛn luthɛɹ pɛndʒɹæɡ mɑndwɪn, sʌn ə ðə hɔkwɪŋ, fɝs feɪs ði ɑɹmiz ə ðə naɪt, hi faʊn mɛni əmʌŋ əm u kɔl ðɛmsɛlvz ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðeɪ kəntɛndɪd fəɹ paʊɝ əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz ən juz ðə wʌn paʊɝ ɑn ðə fild ə bæɾəl. wʌn sʌtʃ, ə wʊmən neɪm din, hu θɔt ʃi kəd də bɛɾɝ sɝvɪŋ ði ɛmpɝɝ - hi wɑz nɑɾ ɛmpɝɝ ðɛn, ʌv kɔɹs - sɪns i hæd noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ɪz ɑɹmiz, keɪm tə hɪm wɪð ə dɪvaɪs ʃi hæd meɪd, ðə fɝst æɾəm, fæsən tə ðə nɛk ʌv wʌn ə hɝ sɪstɝz. ðoʊ ðət wʊmən dɪd nɑt wɑnə sɝv luthɛɹ, ði æɾəm ɹikwaɪɝɾ əɹ tə sɝv. din meɪd mɔɹ æɾəm, ðə fɝst sʌldəm wɝ faʊnd, ən wɪmən kæptʃɝɾ u kɔl ðɛmsɛlvz ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪskʌvɝd ðət ðeɪ wɝ ɪn fækt oʊnli mɛɹəθdəmeɪn, ðoʊz u mʌs bi liʃt. ɪts sɛd ðət wən ʃi hɝsɛlf wɑz liʃt, dinz skɹimz ʃʊk ðə taʊɝz ə mɪdnaɪt, bʌɾ ə kɔɹs ʃi, tu, wɑz ə mɛɹəθdəmeɪn, ən mɛɹəθdəmeɪn kænɑt bi əlaʊd tə ɹʌn fɹi. pɝhæps jəl bi wʌn ə ðoʊz u hæz ði əbɪləɾi tə meɪk æɾəm. ɪf soʊ, jəl bi pæmpɝd, jə meɪ ɹɛst əʃʊɹd."

Egwene knew incredulity must be painting her face, because Renna laughed openly. "When Luthair Paendrag Mondwin, son of the Hawkwing, first faced the Armies of the Night, he found many among them who called themselves Aes Sedai. They contended for power among themselves and used the One Power on the field of battle. One such, a woman named Deain, who thought she could do better serving the Emperor - he was not Emperor then, of course - since he had no Aes Sedai in his armies, came to him with a device she had made, the first a'dam, fastened to the neck of one of her sisters. Though that woman did not want to serve Luthair, the a'dam required her to serve. Deain made more a'dam, the first sul'dam were found, and women captured who called themselves Aes Sedai discovered that they were in fact only marath'damane, Those Who Must Be Leashed. It is said that when she herself was leashed, Deain's screams shook the Towers of Midnight, but of course she, too, was a marath'damane, and marath'damane cannot be allowed to run free. Perhaps you will be one of those who has the ability to make a'dam. If so, you will be pampered, you may rest assured."

ɛɡwin lʊk jɝnɪŋli ət ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd θɹu wɪtʃ ðeɪ ɹoʊd. ðə lænd wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə ɹaɪz ɪn loʊ hɪlz, ən ðə θɪn fɔɹəs hæd dwɪndəl tə skæɾɝd θɪkəts, bʌt ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ʃi kəd luz hɝsɛlf ɪn ðɛm. "æm aɪ səpoʊz tə lʊk fɔɹwɝd tə biɪŋ pæmpɝd laɪk ə pɛt dɔɡ?" ʃi sɛd bɪɾɝli. "ə laɪftaɪm ə biɪŋ tʃeɪn tə mɛn ən wɪmən u θɪŋk aɪm səm kaɪndə ænəməl?"

Egwene looked yearningly at the countryside through which they rode. The land was beginning to rise in low hills, and the thin forest had dwindled to scattered thickets, but she was sure she could lose herself in them. "Am I supposed to look forward to being pampered like a pet dog?" she said bitterly. "A lifetime of being chained to men and women who think I am some kind of animal?"

"nɑt mɛn." ɹɛnə tʃʌkəld. "ɔl sʌldəm ɑɹ wɪmən. ɪf ə mæn pʊɾ ɑn ðɪs bɹeɪslət, moʊst ə ðə taɪm ɪt wəd bi noʊ dɪfɹən ðən ɪf ɪt wɝ hæŋɪŋ ɑn ə pɛɡ ɑn ðə wɔl."

"Not men." Renna chuckled. "All sul'dam are women. If a man put on this bracelet, most of the time it would be no different than if it were hanging on a peg on the wall."

"æn səmtaɪmz," ðə blu-aɪd sʌldəm pʊɾ ɪn hɑɹʃli, "ju ən i wəd boʊθ daɪ skɹimɪŋ." ðə wʊmən hæd ʃɑɹp fitʃɝz ən ə taɪt, θɪn-lɪp maʊθ, ən ɛɡwin ɹilaɪz ðəɾ æŋɡɝ wɑz əpɛɹənli hɝ pɝmənən ɪkspɹɛʃən. "fɹʌm taɪm tə taɪm ði ɛmpɹɛs pleɪz wɪð lɔɹdz baɪ lɪŋkɪŋ əm tə ə deɪmeɪn. ɪt meɪks ðə lɔɹdz swɛɾ ən ɛntɝteɪnz ðə kɔɹɾ ə ðə naɪn munz. ðə lɔɹd nɛvɝ noʊz əntɪl ɪts dʌn wɛðɝ hɪl lɪv əɹ daɪ, ən niðɝ dʌz ðə deɪmeɪn." hɝ læf wɑz vɪʃəs.

"And sometimes," the blue-eyed sul'dam put in harshly, "you and he would both die screaming." The woman had sharp features and a tight, thin-lipped mouth, and Egwene realized that anger was apparently her permanent expression. "From time to time the Empress plays with lords by linking them to a damane. It makes the lords sweat and entertains the Court of the Nine Moons. The lord never knows until it is done whether he will live or die, and neither does the damane." Her laugh was vicious.

"oʊnli ði ɛmpɹɛs kən əfɔɹd tə weɪs deɪmeɪn ɪn sətʃ ə weɪ, ælwɪn," ɹɛnə snæpt, "æn aɪ də nɑt min tə tʃɹeɪn ðɪs deɪmeɪn oʊnli tə hæv əɹ θɹoʊn əweɪ."

"Only the Empress can afford to waste damane in such a way, Alwhin," Renna snapped, "and I do not mean to train this damane only to have her thrown away."

"aɪ hæv nɑt sin ɛni tʃɹeɪnɪŋ əɾ ɔl soʊ fɑɹ, ɹɛnə. oʊnli ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə tʃæɾɝ, əz ɪf jə ən ðɪs deɪmeɪn wɝ ɡɝlhʊd fɹɛnz."

"I have not seen any training at all so far, Renna. Only a great deal of chatter, as if you and this damane were girlhood friends."

"pɝhæps ɪts taɪm tə si wʌt ʃi kən du," ɹɛnə sɛd, stʌɾiɪŋ ɛɡwin. "du juv ɪnʌf kəntʃɹoʊl jɛt tə tʃænəl ət ðət dɪstəns?" ʃi pɔɪntəd tə ə tɔl oʊk stændɪŋ əloʊn ɑn ə hɪltɑp.

"Perhaps it is time to see what she can do," Renna said, studying Egwene. "Do you have enough control yet to channel at that distance?" She pointed to a tall oak standing alone on a hilltop.

ɛɡwin fɹaʊn ət ðə tʃɹi, pɝhæps hæf ə maɪl fɹəm ðə laɪn fɑloʊd baɪ ðə soʊlʒɝz ən sjuɹɔθs pɑlɑnkwɪn. ʃi hæd nɛvɝ tʃɹaɪɾ ɛniθɪŋ mʌtʃ bɪɑn ɑɹmz ɹitʃ, bʌt ʃi θɔɾ ɪt maɪt bi pɑsəbəl. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ," ʃi sɛd.

Egwene frowned at the tree, perhaps half a mile from the line followed by the soldiers and Suroth's palanquin. She had never tried anything much beyond arm's reach, but she thought it might be possible. "I don't know," she said.

"tʃɹaɪ," ɹɛnə toʊl hɝ. "fil ðə tʃɹi. fil ðə sæp ɪn ðə tʃɹi. aɪ wɑn jə tə meɪk ɪɾ ɔl nɑɾ oʊnli hɑt, bʌt soʊ hɑt ðəɾ ɛvɹi dʒɹɑp ə sæp ɪn ɛvɹi bɹæntʃ flæʃɪz tə stim ɪn ən ɪnstənt. də ɪt."

"Try," Renna told her. "Feel the tree. Feel the sap in the tree. I want you to make it all not only hot, but so hot that every drop of sap in every branch flashes to steam in an instant. Do it."

ɛɡwin wɑz ʃɑk tə dɪskʌvɝ ən ɝdʒ tə də əz ɹɛnə kəmændəd. ʃi hæd nɑt tʃænəld, əɹ ivən tʌtʃt seɪaɪdɑɹ, ɪn tu deɪz; ðə dɪzaɪɝ tə fɪl hɝsɛlf wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ meɪɾ əɹ ʃɪvɝ. "aɪ" - ɪn hæf ə hɑɹtbit ʃi dɪskɑɹɾɪd "wɪl nɑt"; ðə wɛlz ðət wɝ nɑt ðəɹ stɪl bɝn tu ʃɑɹpli fəɹ əɹ tə bi kwaɪt ðət fulɪʃ - "kænɑt," ʃi fɪnɪʃt ɪnstɛd. "ɪɾ ɪz tu fɑɹ, ən aɪv nɛvɝ dʌn ɛniθɪŋ laɪk ðət bɪfɔɹ."

Egwene was shocked to discover an urge to do as Renna commanded. She had not channeled, or even touched saidar, in two days; the desire to fill herself with the One Power made her shiver. "I" - in half a heartbeat she discarded "will not"; the weals that were not there still burned too sharply for her to be quite that foolish - "cannot," she finished instead. "It is too far, and I've never done anything like that before."

wʌn ə ðə sʌldəm læft ɹɔkəsli, ən ælwɪn sɛd, "ʃi nɛvɝ ivən tʃɹaɪd."

One of the sul'dam laughed raucously, and Alwhin said, "She never even tried."

ɹɛnə ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ ɔlmoʊst sædli. "wɛn wʌn əz bɪn ə sʌldəm lɔŋ ɪnʌf," ʃi toʊld ɛɡwin, "wʌn lɝnz tə tɛl mɛni θɪŋz əbaʊt deɪmeɪn ivən wɪθaʊt ðə bɹeɪslət, bʌt wɪð ðə bɹeɪslət wʌn kən ɔlweɪz tɛl wɛðɝ ə deɪmeɪn əz tʃɹaɪd tə tʃænəl. jə mʌs nɛvɝ laɪ tə mi, əɹ tə ɛni sʌldəm, nɑɾ ivən baɪ ə hɛɹ."

Renna shook her head almost sadly. "When one has been a sul'dam long enough," she told Egwene, "one learns to tell many things about damane even without the bracelet, but with the bracelet one can always tell whether a damane has tried to channel. You must never lie to me, or to any sul'dam, not even by a hair."

sʌɾənli ði ɪnvɪzəbəl swɪtʃəz wɝ bæk, stʃɹaɪkɪŋ əɾ əɹ ɛvɹiwɛɹ. jɛlɪŋ, ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə hɪt ɹɛnə, bʌt ðə sʌldəm kæʒəwəli nɑkt əɹ fɪst əweɪ, ən ɛɡwin fɛlt əz ɪf ɹɛnə hæd hɪɾ əɹ ɑɹm wɪð ə stɪk. ʃi dʌɡ hɝ hilz ɪndə bɛləz flæŋks, bʌt ðə sʌldəmz ɡɹɪp ɑn ðə liʃ nɪɹli pʊld əɹ aʊɾ ə hɝ sæɾəl. fɹæntəkəli ʃi ɹitʃt fəɹ seɪaɪdɑɹ, minɪŋ tə hɝt ɹɛnə ɪnʌf tə meɪk əɹ stɑp, dʒʌs ðə kaɪndə hɝt ʃi hɝsɛlf hæd bɪn ɡɪvən. ðə sʌldəm ʃʊk əɹ hɛd ɹaɪli; ɛɡwin haʊld əz əɹ oʊn skɪn wɑz sʌɾənli skɔldɪd. nɑɾ əntɪl ʃi flɛd fɹəm seɪaɪdɑɹ kəmplitli dɪd ðə bɝn bɪɡɪn tə feɪd, ən ði ənsin bloʊz nɛvɝ sist əɹ sloʊd. ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə ʃaʊt ðət ʃi wəd tʃɹaɪ, ɪf oʊnli ɹɛnə wəd stɑp, bʌɾ ɔl ʃi kəd mænədʒ wɑz tə skɹim ən ɹɪð.

Suddenly the invisible switches were back, striking at her everywhere. Yelling, she tried to hit Renna, but the sul'dam casually knocked her fist away, and Egwene felt as if Renna had hit her arm with a stick. She dug her heels into Bela's flanks, but the sul'dam's grip on the leash nearly pulled her out of her saddle. Frantically she reached for saidar, meaning to hurt Renna enough to make her stop, just the kind of hurt she herself had been given. The sul'dam shook her head wryly; Egwene howled as her own skin was suddenly scalded. Not until she fled from saidar completely did the burn begin to fade, and the unseen blows never ceased or slowed. She tried to shout that she would try, if only Renna would stop, but all she could manage was to scream and writhe.

dɪmli, ʃi wɑz əwɛɹ ə mɪn ʃaʊɾɪŋ æŋɡɹəli ən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹaɪd tə hɝ saɪd, ʌv ælwɪn tɛɹɪŋ mɪnz ɹeɪnz fɹəm əɹ hænz, ʌv ənʌðɝ sʌldəm spikɪŋ ʃɑɹpli tə hɝ deɪmeɪn, hu lʊkt ət mɪn. ən ðən mɪn wɑz jɛlɪŋ, tu, ɑɹmz flæpɪŋ əz ɪf tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə wɔɹɾ ɔf bloʊz əɹ biɾ əweɪ stɪŋɪŋ ɪnsɛks. ɪn əɹ oʊn peɪn, mɪnz sim dɪstənt.

Dimly, she was aware of Min shouting angrily and trying to ride to her side, of Alwhin tearing Min's reins from her hands, of another sul'dam speaking sharply to her damane, who looked at Min. And then Min was yelling, too, arms flapping as if trying to ward off blows or beat away stinging insects. In her own pain, Min's seemed distant.

ðɛɹ kɹaɪz təɡɛðɝ wɝ ɪnʌf tə meɪk səm ə ðə soʊlʒɝz twɪst ɪn ðɛɹ sæɾəlz. æftɝ wʌn lʊk, ðeɪ læft ən tɝn bæk. haʊ sʌldəm dɛlt wɪð deɪmeɪn wɑz noʊ əfɛɹ ə ðɛɹz.

Their cries together were enough to make some of the soldiers twist in their saddles. After one look, they laughed and turned back. How sul'dam dealt with damane was no affair of theirs.

tə ɛɡwin ɪt sim tə ɡoʊ ɑn fɝɛvɝ, bʌɾ ət læs ðəɹ wɑz ən ɛnd. ʃi leɪ spɹɔld wikli əkɹɔs ðə kæntəl ə hɝ sæɾəl, tʃiks wɛt wɪð tɪɹz, sɑbɪŋ ɪndə bɛləz meɪn. ðə mɛɹ wɪkɝɾ ənizəli.

To Egwene it seemed to go on forever, but at last there was an end. She lay sprawled weakly across the cantle of her saddle, cheeks wet with tears, sobbing into Bela's mane. The mare whickered uneasily.

"ɪɾ ɪz ɡʊd ðət juv spɪɹət," ɹɛnə sɛd kɑmli. "ðə bɛs deɪmeɪn ɑɹ ðoʊz u hæv spɪɹət tə bi ʃeɪpt ən moʊldəd."

"It is good that you have spirit," Renna said calmly. "The best damane are those who have spirit to be shaped and molded."

ɛɡwin skwizd əɹ aɪz ʃʌt. ʃi wɪʃt ʃi kəd kloʊz əɹ ɪɹz, tu, tə ʃʌɾ aʊt ɹɛnəz vɔɪs. aɪ hæv tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ. aɪ hæv tə, bʌt haʊ? nɪneɪiv, hɛlp mi. laɪt, sʌmbɑɾi hɛlp mi.

Egwene squeezed her eyes shut. She wished she could close her ears, too, to shut out Renna's voice. I have to get away. I have to, but how? Nynaeve, help me. Light, somebody help me.

"ju wɪl bi wʌn ə ðə bɛst," ɹɛnə sɛɾ ɪn toʊnz ə sæɾəsfækʃən. hɝ hæn stʃɹoʊkt ɛɡwinz hɛɹ, ə mɪstʃɹəs suðɪŋ əɹ dɔɡ.

"You will be one of the best," Renna said in tones of satisfaction. Her hand stroked Egwene's hair, a mistress soothing her dog.

nɪneɪiv lin aʊɾ ə hɝ sæɾəl tə pɪɹ ɝaʊn ðə skɹin ə pɹɪkli lift ʃɹʌbz. skæɾɝd tʃɹiz mɛɾ əɹ aɪz, səm wɪð livz tɝnɪŋ kʌlɝ. ði ɪkspænsɪz ʌv ɡɹæs ən bɹʌʃ bɪtwin simd ɛmpti. nʌθɪŋ muv ðət ʃi kəd si ɪksɛp ðə θɪnɪŋ kɑləm ə smoʊk, weɪvɝɪŋ ɪn ə bɹiz, fɹəm ðə lɛðɝlif.

Nynaeve leaned out of her saddle to peer around the screen of prickly leafed shrubs. Scattered trees met her eyes, some with leaves turning color. The expanses of grass and brush between seemed empty. Nothing moved that she could see except the thinning column of smoke, wavering in a breeze, from the leatherleaf.

ðət hæd bɪn əɹ wɝk, ðə lɛðɝlif, ən wʌns ðə laɪtnɪŋ kɔl fɹəm ə klɪɹ skaɪ, ən ə fju ʌðɝ θɪŋz ʃi hæd nɑt θɔt tə tʃɹaɪ əntɪl ðoʊz tu wɪmən tʃɹaɪɾ əm ɑn hɝ. ʃi θɔt ðeɪ mʌst wɝk təɡɛðɝ ɪn səm weɪ, ðoʊ ʃi kəd nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ðɛɹ ɹileɪʃən tə itʃ ʌðɝ, əpɛɹənli liʃt əz ðeɪ wɝ. wʌn wɔɹ ə kɑlɝ, bʌt ði ʌðɝ wɑz tʃeɪn əz ʃʊɹli əz ʃi. wʌt nɪneɪiv wɑz ʃʊɹ ʌv wɑz ðət wʌn əɹ boʊθ wɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ʃi hæd nɛvɝ hæɾ ə klɪɹ ɪnʌf saɪɾ ə ðɛm tə si ðə ɡloʊ ʌv tʃænəlɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪt hæd tə bi.

That had been her work, the leatherleaf, and once the lightning called from a clear sky, and a few other things she had not thought to try until those two women tried them on her. She thought they must work together in some way, though she could not understand their relation to each other, apparently leashed as they were. One wore a collar, but the other was chained as surely as she. What Nynaeve was sure of was that one or both were Aes Sedai. She had never had a clear enough sight of them to see the glow of channeling, but it had to be.

əl sɝɾənli teɪk plɛʒɝ ɪn tɛlɪŋ ʃɛɹiəm əbaʊt ðɛm, ʃi θɔt dʒɹaɪli. ɛɛs sədaɪ doʊn juz ðə paʊɝ əz ə wɛpən, də ðeɪ?

I'll certainly take pleasure in telling Sheriam about them, she thought dryly. Aes Sedai don't use the Power as a weapon, do they?

ʃi sɝɾənli hæd. ʃi hæɾ ət lis nɑk ðə tu wɪmən daʊn wɪð ðət laɪtnɪŋ stʃɹaɪk, ən ʃi hæd sin wʌn ə ðə soʊlʒɝz, əɹ ɪz bɑɾi ɹæðɝ, bɝn fɹəm ðə bɔl ə faɪɝ ʃi meɪɾ ən hɝld ət ðɛm. bʌt ʃi hæd nɑt sin ɛni ʌv ðə stʃɹeɪnʒɝz əɾ ɔl ɪn səm taɪm naʊ.

She certainly had. She had at least knocked the two women down with that lightning strike, and she had seen one of the soldiers, or his body rather, burn from the ball of fire she made and hurled at them. But she had not seen any of the strangers at all in some time now.

swɛt biɾɪd ɑn əɹ fɔɹhɛd, ən ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ɔl fɹəm ɪɡzɝʃən. hɝ kɑntækt wɪð seɪaɪdɑɹ wɑz ɡɔn, ən ʃi kəd nɑt bɹɪŋ ɪt bæk. ɪn ðət fɝs fjʊɹi ʌv noʊɪŋ ðət liɑnʒɹɪn hæd bɪtʃɹeɪd ðɛm, seɪaɪdɑɹ hæd bɪn ðəɹ ɔlmoʊs bɪfɔɹ ʃi nu ɪt, ðə wʌn paʊɝ flʌɾɪŋ hɝ. ɪt hæd simd ʃi kəd də ɛniθɪŋ. ən əz lɔŋ əz ðeɪ hæd tʃeɪs hɝ, ɹeɪdʒ ət biɪŋ hʌntəd laɪk ən ænəməl hæd fjuəl hɝ. naʊ ðə tʃeɪs hæd vænɪʃt. ðə lɔŋɡɝ ʃi hæd ɡɔn wɪθaʊt siɪŋ ən ɛnəmi ət hum ʃi kəd stʃɹaɪk, ðə mɔɹ ʃi hæd bɪɡʌn tə wɝi ðət ðeɪ maɪt bi snikɪŋ ʌp ɑn əɹ sʌmhaʊ, ən ðə mɔɹ ʃi hæd hæd taɪm tə wɝi əbaʊt wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ tə ɛɡwin, ən ɪleɪn, ən mɪn. naʊ ʃi wɑz fɔɹs tə ədmɪt ðət wʌt ʃi fɛl moʊst wɑz fɪɹ. fɪɹ fəɹ ðɛm, fɪɹ fəɹ hɝsɛlf. ɪt wɑz æŋɡɝ ʃi niɾəd.

Sweat beaded on her forehead, and it was not all from exertion. Her contact with saidar was gone, and she could not bring it back. In that first fury of knowing that Liandrin had betrayed them, saidar had been there almost before she knew it, the One Power flooding her. It had seemed she could do anything. And as long as they had chased her, rage at being hunted like an animal had fueled her. Now the chase had vanished. The longer she had gone without seeing an enemy at whom she could strike, the more she had begun to worry that they might be sneaking up on her somehow, and the more she had had time to worry about what was happening to Egwene, and Elayne, and Min. Now she was forced to admit that what she felt most was fear. Fear for them, fear for herself. It was anger she needed.

sʌmθɪŋ stɝd bɪhaɪn ə tʃɹi.

Something stirred behind a tree.

hɝ bɹɛθ kɑt, ən ʃi fʌmbəl fəɹ seɪaɪdɑɹ, bʌɾ ɔl ði ɛksɝsaɪzəz ʃɛɹiəm ən ði ʌðɝz hæd tɔt hɝ, ɔl ðə blɑsəmz ənfoʊldɪŋ ɪn əɹ maɪnd, ɔl ði ɪmædʒən stʃɹimz ðət ʃi hɛld laɪk ɹɪvɝbɑŋks, dɪd noʊ ɡʊd. ʃi kəd fil ɪt, sɛns ðə sɔɹs, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt tʌtʃ ɪt.

Her breath caught, and she fumbled for saidar, but all the exercises Sheriam and the others had taught her, all the blossoms unfolding in her mind, all the imagined streams that she held like riverbanks, did no good. She could feel it, sense the Source, but she could not touch it.

ɪleɪn stɛp fɹəm bɪhaɪn ðə tʃɹi ɪn ə wɛɹi kɹaʊtʃ, ən nɪneɪiv sæɡd wɪð ɹɪlif. ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹz dʒɹɛs wɑz dɝɾi ən tɔɹn, hɝ ɡoʊldən hɛɹ wɑz ə tæŋɡəl ə snɑɹlz ən livz, ən əɹ sɝtʃɪŋ aɪz wɝ əz waɪɾ əz ðoʊz ʌv ə fɹaɪɾənd fɔn, bʌt ʃi hɛld əɹ ʃɔɹt-bleɪɾɪd dæɡɝ ɪn ə stɛɾi hænd. nɪneɪiv pɪkt ʌp əɹ ɹeɪnz ən ɹoʊɾ ɪndə ði oʊpən.

Elayne stepped from behind the tree in a wary crouch, and Nynaeve sagged with relief. The Daughter-Heir's dress was dirty and torn, her golden hair was a tangle of snarls and leaves, and her searching eyes were as wide as those of a frightened fawn, but she held her short-bladed dagger in a steady hand. Nynaeve picked up her reins and rode into the open.

ɪleɪn ɡeɪv ə kənvʌlsɪv dʒʌmp, ðən əɹ hænd wɛn tə hɝ θɹoʊɾ ən ʃi dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ. nɪneɪiv dɪsmaʊntɪd, ən ðə tu wɪmən hʌɡd, teɪkɪŋ kʌmfɝɾ ɪn hævɪŋ faʊn itʃ ʌðɝ.

Elayne gave a convulsive jump, then her hand went to her throat and she drew a deep breath. Nynaeve dismounted, and the two women hugged, taking comfort in having found each other.

"fɔɹ ə moʊmənt," ɪleɪn sɛɾ əz ðeɪ faɪnəli stɛpt əpɑɹt, "aɪ θɔt jə wɝ. . . . dʒju noʊ wɛɹ ðeɪ ɑɹ? ðəɹ wɝ tu mɛn fɑloʊɪŋ mi. ənʌðɝ fju mɪnəts ən ðeɪ wʊɾə kɑt mi, bʌɾ ə hɔɹn saʊndəɾ ən ðeɪ tɝn ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz ən ɡæləpt ɔf. ðeɪ kəd si mi, nɪneɪiv, ən ðeɪ dʒʌs lɛft."

"For a moment," Elayne said as they finally stepped apart, "I thought you were. . . . Do you know where they are? There were two men following me. Another few minutes and they would have caught me, but a horn sounded and they turned their horses and galloped off. They could see me, Nynaeve, and they just left."

"aɪ hɝɾ ɪt, tu, ən aɪ hævən sin ɛni ʌv əm sɪns. hæv jə sin ɛɡwin, əɹ mɪn?"

"I heard it, too, and I haven't seen any of them since. Have you seen Egwene, or Min?"

ɪleɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, slʌmpɪŋ tə sɪɾ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. "nɑt sɪns. . . . ðət mæn hɪt mɪn, nɑkt əɹ daʊn. ən wʌn ə ðoʊz wɪmən wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʊt sʌmθɪŋ ɝaʊn ɛɡwinz nɛk. aɪ sɔ ðət mʌtʃ bɪfɔɹ aɪ ɹæn. aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðeɪ ɡɑɾ əweɪ, nɪneɪiv. aɪ ʃʊɾə dʌn sʌmθɪŋ. mɪn kʌt ðə hæn ðət wɑz hoʊldɪŋ mi, ən ɛɡwin. . . . aɪ dʒʌst ɹæn, nɪneɪiv. aɪ ɹilaɪzd aɪ wɑz fɹi, ən aɪ ɹæn. mʌðɝ hæd bɛɾɝ mɛɹi ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn ən əv ənʌðɝ dɔɾɝ əz sun əz ʃi kæn. aɪm nɑt fɪt tə teɪk ðə θɹoʊn."

Elayne shook her head, slumping to sit on the ground. "Not since. . . . That man hit Min, knocked her down. And one of those women was trying to put something around Egwene's neck. I saw that much before I ran. I don't think they got away, Nynaeve. I should have done something. Min cut the hand that was holding me, and Egwene. . . . I just ran, Nynaeve. I realized I was free, and I ran. Mother had better marry Gareth Bryne and have another daughter as soon as she can. I am not fit to take the throne."

"doʊn bi ə ɡus," nɪneɪiv sɛd ʃɑɹpli. "ɹɪmɛmbɝ, aɪ hæv ə pækəɾ ə ʃipstɔŋ ɹuɾ əmʌŋ maɪ ɝbz." ɪleɪn hæɾ əɹ hɛɾ ɪn əɹ hænz; ðə ʒaɪb dɪd nɑɾ ivən pɹədus ə mɝmɝ. "lɪsən tə mi, ɡɝl. dɪd jə si mi steɪ tə faɪt twɛnti əɹ θɝɾi ɑɹmd mɛn, nɑt tə mɛnʃən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ? ɪf jə hæd weɪɾəd, ðə moʊs laɪkli θɪŋ baɪ fɑɹ ɪz ðət jə wəd bi ə pɹɪznɝ, tu. ɪf ðeɪ dɪdn dʒʌs kɪl ju. ðeɪ sim tə bi ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn ɛɡwin ən mi fəɹ səm ɹizən. ðeɪ maɪt nɑɾ əv kɛɹd wɛðɝ jə ɹɪmeɪn əlaɪv əɹ nɑt." waɪ ɑɹ ðeɪ ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn ɛɡwin ən mi? waɪ əs ɪn pɝtɪkjəlɝ? waɪ dɪd liɑnʒɹɪn də ðɪs? waɪ? ʃi hæd noʊ mɔɹ ænsɝz naʊ ðən ʃi hæd hæd ðə fɝs taɪm ʃi æsk hɝsɛlf ðiz kwɛstʃənz.

"Don't be a goose," Nynaeve said sharply. "Remember, I have a packet of sheepstongue root among my herbs." Elayne had her head in her hands; the gibe did not even produce a murmur. "Listen to me, girl. Did you see me stay to fight twenty or thirty armed men, not to mention the Aes Sedai? If you had waited, the most likely thing by far is that you would be a prisoner, too. If they didn't just kill you. They seemed to be interested in Egwene and me for some reason. They might not have cared whether you remained alive or not." Why are they interested in Egwene and me? Why us in particular? Why did Liandrin do this? Why? She had no more answers now than she had had the first time she asked herself these questions.

"ɪf aɪ hæd daɪd tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə hɛlp əm - " ɪleɪn bɪɡæn.

"If I had died trying to help them - " Elayne began.

" - jud bi dɛd. ən lɪɾəl ɡʊd jud bi ðɛn, tə jɝsɛlf əɹ ðɛm. naʊ ɡɛɾ ɑn jəɹ fiɾ ən bɹʌʃ ɔf jəɹ dʒɹɛs." nɪneɪiv ɹʌmɪɡd ɪn əɹ sæɾəlbæɡz fəɹ ə hɛɹbɹʌʃ. "æn fɪks jəɹ hɛɹ."

" - you'd be dead. And little good you'd be then, to yourself or them. Now get on your feet and brush off your dress." Nynaeve rummaged in her saddlebags for a hairbrush. "And fix your hair."

ɪleɪn ɡɑɾ ʌp sloʊli, ən tʊk ðə bɹʌʃ wɪð ə smɔl læf. "ju saʊn laɪk lini, maɪ oʊl nɝs." ʃi bɪɡæn tə ɹʌn ðə bɹʌʃ θɹu hɝ hɛɹ, wɪnsɪŋ əz tæŋɡəlz pʊld. "bʌt haʊ ɑɹ wi gɑnə hɛlp ðɛm, nɪneɪiv? jə meɪ bi əz stʃɹɔŋ əz ə fʊl sɪstɝ wən jə ɑɹ æŋɡɹi, bʌt ðeɪv wɪmən u kən tʃænəl, tu. aɪ kænɑt θɪŋk ðəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌt ðeɪ maɪɾ əz wɛl bi. wi də nɑɾ ivən noʊ ɪn wɪtʃ dɝɛkʃən ðeɪ tʊk ðɛm."

Elayne got up slowly, and took the brush with a small laugh. "You sound like Lini, my old nurse." She began to run the brush through her hair, wincing as tangles pulled. "But how are we going to help them, Nynaeve? You may be as strong as a full sister when you are angry, but they have women who can channel, too. I cannot think they're Aes Sedai, but they might as well be. We do not even know in which direction they took them."

"wɛst," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "ðæt kɹitʃɝ sjuɹɔθ mɛnʃən fɑlm, ən ðæts əz fɑɹ wɛst ɑn toʊmən hɛɾ əz jə kən ɡoʊ. wɪl ɡoʊ tə fɑlm. aɪ hoʊp liɑnʒɹɪn ɪz ðɛɹ. əl meɪk əɹ kɝs ðə deɪ hɝ mʌðɝ leɪɾ aɪz ɑn əɹ fɑðɝ. bʌt fɝst aɪ θɪŋk wi hæd bɛɾɝ faɪn səm kloʊðz ə ðə kʌntʃɹi. aɪv sin tæɹɑbənɝ ən dəmɑni wɪmən ɪn ðə taʊɝ, ən wʌt ðeɪ wɛɹ ɪz nʌθɪŋ laɪk wʌt wɪv ɑn. wi wəd stæn aʊɾ ɪn fɑlm əz stʃɹeɪnʒɝz."

"West," Nynaeve said. "That creature Suroth mentioned Falme, and that's as far west on Toman Head as you can go. We will go to Falme. I hope Liandrin is there. I will make her curse the day her mother laid eyes on her father. But first I think we had better find some clothes of the country. I've seen Taraboner and Domani women in the Tower, and what they wear is nothing like what we have on. We would stand out in Falme as strangers."

"aɪ wəd nɑt maɪn ə dəmɑni dʒɹɛs - ðoʊ mʌðɝ wəd ʃʊɹli hæv ə fɪɾ ɪf ʃi ɛvɝ faʊn aʊɾ aɪd wɔɹn wʌn, ən lini wəd nɛvɝ lemi hɪɹ ði ɛn ʌv ɪt - bʌɾ ivən ɪf wi faɪn ə vɪlədʒ, kən wi əfɔɹd nu dʒɹɛsəz? aɪ hæv noʊ aɪdiə haʊ mʌtʃ mʌni jə hæv, bʌɾ aɪ hæv oʊnli tɛn ɡoʊl mɑɹks ən pɝhæps twaɪs ðəɾ ɪn sɪlvɝ. ðət wɪl kip əs tu əɹ θɹi wiks, bʌɾ aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt wɪl də æftɝ ðæt."

"I would not mind a Domani dress - though Mother would surely have a fit if she ever found out I'd worn one, and Lini would never let me hear the end of it - but even if we find a village, can we afford new dresses? I have no idea how much money you have, but I have only ten gold marks and perhaps twice that in silver. That will keep us two or three weeks, but I don't know what we will do after that."

"ə fju mʌnθs əz ə nɑvəs ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn," nɪneɪiv sɛd, læfɪŋ, "hæz nɑt stɑp jə θɪŋkɪŋ laɪk ði ɛɹ tə ə θɹoʊn. aɪ doʊn əv ə tɛnθ wʌt jə du, bʌɾ ɔltəɡɛðɝ ɪɾəl kip əs tu əɹ θɹi mʌnθs, ɪn kʌmfɝt. lɔŋɡɝ, ɪf wəɹ kɛɹfəl. aɪ hæv noʊ ɪntɛntʃən ə baɪɪŋ əs dʒɹɛsəz, ən ðeɪ woʊn bi nu ɪn ɛni keɪs. maɪ ɡɹeɪ sɪlk dʒɹɛs wɪl də əs səm ɡʊd, wɪð ɔl ðoʊz pɝlz ən ðət ɡoʊl θɹɛd. ɪf aɪ kæn faɪn ə wʊmən u wɪl tʃɹeɪɾ əs itʃ tu əɹ θɹi stɝɾi tʃeɪnʒəz fəɹ ðæt, əl ɡɪv jə ðɪs ɹɪŋ, ən əl bi ðə nɑvəs." ʃi swʌŋ ʌp ɪndə hɝ sæɾəl ən ɹitʃt ə hæn daʊn tə pʊl ɪleɪn ʌp bɪhaɪn hɝ.

"A few months as a novice in Tar Valon," Nynaeve said, laughing, "has not stopped you thinking like the heir to a throne. I don't have a tenth what you do, but altogether it will keep us two or three months, in comfort. Longer, if we are careful. I have no intention of buying us dresses, and they won't be new in any case. My gray silk dress will do us some good, with all those pearls and that gold thread. If I can't find a woman who will trade us each two or three sturdy changes for that, I will give you this ring, and I will be the novice." She swung up into her saddle and reached a hand down to pull Elayne up behind her.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ wi gɑnə də wən wi ɹitʃ fɑlm?" ɪleɪn æskt əz ʃi sɛɾəld ɑn ðə mɛɹz ɹʌmp.

"What are we going to do when we reach Falme?" Elayne asked as she settled on the mare's rump.

"aɪ woʊnt noʊ ðəɾ əntɪl wəɹ ðɛɹ." nɪneɪiv pɔzd, lɛɾɪŋ ðə hɔɹs stænd. "ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ jə wɑnə də ðɪs? ɪɾəl bi deɪnʒɝəs."

"I won't know that until we are there." Nynaeve paused, letting the horse stand. "Are you sure you want to do this? It will be dangerous."

"mɔɹ deɪnʒɝəs ðən ɪts fəɹ ɛɡwin ən mɪn? ðeɪ wəd kʌm æftɝ əs ɪf əɹ sɝkəmstænsəz wɝ ɹɪvɝst; aɪ noʊ ðeɪ wʊd. ɑɹ wi gɑnə steɪ hɪɹ ɔl deɪ?" ɪleɪn dʌɡ hɝ hilz ɪn, ən ðə mɛɹ stɑɹɾəd ɔf.

"More dangerous than it is for Egwene and Min? They would come after us if our circumstances were reversed; I know they would. Are we going to stay here all day?" Elayne dug her heels in, and the mare started off.

nɪneɪiv tɝn ðə hɔɹs əntɪl ðə sʌn, stɪl ʃɔɹɾ ʌv ɪts nundeɪ kɹɛst, ʃoʊn ət ðɛɹ bæks. "wi ɑɹ gɑnə hæv tə bi kɔʃəs. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wi noʊ kən ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ə wʊmən u kən tʃænəl dʒʌs baɪ biɪŋ wɪðɪn ɑɹmz lɛŋθ ə hɝ. ðiz ɛɛs sədaɪ meɪ bi eɪbəl tə pɪk əs aʊɾ ʌv ə kɹaʊɾ ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹ lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ʌs, ən wi hæd bɛɾɝ əsum ðeɪ ɑɹ." ðeɪ wɝ sɝɾənli lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ɛɡwin ən mi. bʌt waɪ?

Nynaeve turned the horse until the sun, still short of its noonday crest, shone at their backs. "We are going to have to be cautious. The Aes Sedai we know can recognize a woman who can channel just by being within arm's length of her. These Aes Sedai may be able to pick us out of a crowd if they are looking for us, and we had better assume they are." They were certainly looking for Egwene and me. But why?

"jɛs, kɔʃəs. jə wɝ ɹaɪt bɪfɔɹ, tu. wɪl nɑt də ðɛm ɛni ɡʊd lɛɾɪŋ aʊɝsɛlvz bi kɑɾ əz wɛl." ɪleɪn wɑz saɪlən fəɹ ə moʊmənt. "du jə θɪŋk ɪt wɑz ɔl laɪz, nɪneɪiv? wʌt liɑnʒɹɪn toʊld əs əbaʊt ɹænd biɪŋ ɪn deɪnʒɝ? ən ði ʌðɝz? ɛɛs sədaɪ də nɑt laɪ."

"Yes, cautious. You were right before, too. We will not do them any good letting ourselves be caught as well." Elayne was silent for a moment. "Do you think it was all lies, Nynaeve? What Liandrin told us about Rand being in danger? And the others? Aes Sedai do not lie."

ɪt wɑz nɪneɪivz tɝn tə bi saɪlənt, ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ʃɛɹiəm tɛlɪŋ əɹ ə ði oʊðz ə wʊmən tʊk ɑn biɪŋ ɹeɪz tə fʊl sɪstɝhʊd, oʊðz spoʊkən hoʊldɪŋ ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil ðət baʊn əɹ tə kip ðɛm. tə spik noʊ wɝd ðəɾ ɪz nɑt tʃɹu. ðət wɑz wʌn, bʌɾ ɛvɹiwʌn nu ðət ðə tʃɹuθ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛd maɪt nɑt bi ðə tʃɹuθ jə θɔt jə hɝd. "aɪ ɪkspɛkt ɹænd ɪz wɔɹmɪŋ ɪz fiɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝz faɪɝ ɪn fæl dæɹə ðɪs mɪnət," ʃi sɛd. aɪ kænt wɝi əbaʊt hɪm, naʊ. aɪ hæv tə θɪŋk əbaʊɾ ɛɡwin ən mɪn.

It was Nynaeve's turn to be silent, remembering Sheriam telling her of the oaths a woman took on being raised to full sisterhood, oaths spoken holding a ter'angreal that bound her to keep them. To speak no word that is not true. That was one, but everyone knew that the truth an Aes Sedai said might not be the truth you thought you heard. "I expect Rand is warming his feet in front of Lord Agelmar's fire in Fal Dara this minute," she said. I can't worry about him, now. I have to think about Egwene and Min.

"aɪ səpoʊz i ɪz," ɪleɪn sɛd wɪð ə saɪ. ʃi ʃɪftəd bɪhaɪn ðə sæɾəl. "ɪf ɪts vɛɹi fɑɹ tə fɑlm, nɪneɪiv, aɪ ɪkspɛk tə ɹaɪɾ ɪn ðə sæɾəl hæf ðə taɪm. ðɪs ɪz nɑɾ ə vɛɹi kʌmftəɹbəl sit. wɪl nɛvɝ ɹitʃ fɑlm əɾ ɔl ɪf jə lɛt ðɪs hɔɹs sɛɾ əɹ oʊn peɪs ðə hoʊl weɪ."

"I suppose he is," Elayne said with a sigh. She shifted behind the saddle. "If it is very far to Falme, Nynaeve, I expect to ride in the saddle half the time. This is not a very comfortable seat. We will never reach Falme at all if you let this horse set her own pace the whole way."

nɪneɪiv buɾɪd ðə mɛɹ tə ə kwɪk tʃɹɑt, ən ɪleɪn jɛlpt ən kɑɾ əɾ əɹ kloʊk. nɪneɪiv toʊl hɝsɛlf ðət ʃi wəd teɪk ə tɝn ɹaɪɾɪŋ bɪhaɪn ən nɑt kəmpleɪn ɪf ɪleɪn pʊt ðə hɔɹs tə ə ɡæləp, bʌt fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt ʃi ɪɡnɔɹd ðə ɡæsps ə ðə wʊmən baʊnsɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɝ. ʃi wɑz tu bɪzi hoʊpɪŋ ðət baɪ ðə taɪm ðeɪ ɹitʃt fɑlm, ʃi kəd stɑp biɪŋ əfɹeɪɾ ən stɑɹt biɪŋ æŋɡɹi.

Nynaeve booted the mare to a quick trot, and Elayne yelped and caught at her cloak. Nynaeve told herself that she would take a turn riding behind and not complain if Elayne put the horse to a gallop, but for the most part she ignored the gasps of the woman bouncing behind her. She was too busy hoping that by the time they reached Falme, she could stop being afraid and start being angry.

ðə bɹiz fɹɛʃənd, kul ən bɹɪsk wɪð ə hɪn ə koʊl jɛt tə kʌm.

The breeze freshened, cool and brisk with a hint of cold yet to come.


tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾiwʌn


CHAPTER 41

dɪsəɡɹiməns


Disagreements

θʌndɝ ɹʌmbəld əkɹɔs ðə sleɪt-dɑɹk æftɝnun skaɪ. ɹænd pʊl ðə hʊɾ ə hɪz kloʊk fɝðɝ ʌp, hoʊpɪŋ tə kip ət list səm ə ðə koʊld ɹeɪn ɔf. ɹɛd stɛp θɹu mʌɾi pʌɾəlz dɔɡədli. ðə hʊd hʌŋ sɑɾən ɝaʊn ɹændz hɛd, əz ðə ɹɛst ə ðə kloʊk dɪɾ ɝaʊn ɪz ʃoʊldɝz, ən ɪz faɪn blæk koʊt wɑz dʒʌst əz wɛt, ən əz koʊld. ðə tɛmpɹətʃɝ wəd nɑɾ əv fɑɹ tə dʒɹɑp bɪfɔɹ snoʊ əɹ slit keɪm daʊn ɪnstɛɾ ə ɹeɪn. snoʊ wəd fɔl sun, əɡɛn; ðə pipəl ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ ðeɪ hæd pæs θɹu sɛd tu snoʊz hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi kʌm ðɪs jɪɹ. ʃɪvɝɪŋ, ɹænd ɔlmoʊst wɪʃt ɪt wɑz snoʊɪŋ. ðɛn, ət list, hi wəd nɑt bi soʊk tə ðə skɪn.

Thunder rumbled across the slate-dark afternoon sky. Rand pulled the hood of his cloak further up, hoping to keep at least some of the cold rain off. Red stepped through muddy puddles doggedly. The hood hung sodden around Rand's head, as the rest of the cloak did around his shoulders, and his fine black coat was just as wet, and as cold. The temperature would not have far to drop before snow or sleet came down instead of rain. Snow would fall soon, again; the people in the village they had passed through said two snows had already come this year. Shivering, Rand almost wished it was snowing. Then, at least, he would not be soaked to the skin.

ðə kɑləm plɑɾəd əlɔŋ, kipɪŋ ə wɛɹi aɪ ɑn ðə ɹoʊlɪŋ kʌntʃɹi. ɪŋtʃɹz ɡɹeɪ aʊl hʌŋ hɛvəli ivən wən ðə wɪnd ɡʌstɪd. hʊɹɪn səmtaɪmz pʊld ɪz kaʊl bæk tə snɪf ði ɛɹ; hi sɛd niðɝ ɹeɪn nɔɹ koʊl hæɾ ɛni ɪfɛkt ɑn ə tʃɹeɪl, sɝɾənli nɑɾ ɑn ðə kaɪndə tʃɹeɪl i wɑz sikɪŋ, bʌt soʊ fɑɹ ðə snɪfɝ hæd faʊnd nʌθɪŋ. bɪhaɪn hɪm, ɹænd hɝɾ ənoʊ mʌɾɝ ə kɝs. lɔɪəl kɛp tʃɛkɪŋ ɪz sæɾəlbæɡz; hi dɪd nɑt sim tə maɪnd ɡɛɾɪŋ wɛt hɪmsɛlf, bʌɾ i wɝid kəntɪnjuəli əbaʊɾ ɪz bʊks. ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz mɪzɝəbəl ɪksɛp fəɹ vɛɹɪn, hu əpɪɹd tu lɔst ɪn θɔt tə ivən noʊɾəs ðəɾ əɹ hʊd hæd slɪd bæk, ɪkspoʊzɪŋ əɹ feɪs tə ðə ɹeɪn.

The column plodded along, keeping a wary eye on the rolling country. Ingtar's Gray Owl hung heavily even when the wind gusted. Hurin sometimes pulled his cowl back to sniff the air; he said neither rain nor cold had any effect on a trail, certainly not on the kind of trail he was seeking, but so far the sniffer had found nothing. Behind him, Rand heard Uno mutter a curse. Loial kept checking his saddlebags; he did not seem to mind getting wet himself, but he worried continually about his books. Everyone was miserable except for Verin, who appeared too lost in thought to even notice that her hood had slid back, exposing her face to the rain.

"kæn jə də sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ðɪs?" ɹænd dɪmændəɾ ə hɝ. ə smɔl vɔɪs ɪn ðə bæk ə hɪz hɛd toʊld ɪm i kəd də ɪt hɪmsɛlf. ɔl i nid də wɑz ɛmbɹeɪs seɪɾɪn. soʊ swit, ðə kɔl ə seɪɾɪn. tə bi fɪld wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ, tə bi wʌn wɪð ðə stɔɹm. tɝn ðə skaɪz tə sʌnlaɪt, əɹ ɹaɪd ðə stɔɹm əz ɪt ɹeɪdʒd, wɪp ɪt tə fjʊɹi ən skaʊɝ toʊmən hɛd klin fɹəm ðə si tə ðə pleɪn. ɛmbɹeɪs seɪɾɪn. hi səpɹɛs ðə lɔŋɪŋ ɹuθləsli.

"Can't you do something about this?" Rand demanded of her. A small voice in the back of his head told him he could do it himself. All he need do was embrace saidin. So sweet, the call of saidin. To be filled with the One Power, to be one with the storm. Turn the skies to sunlight, or ride the storm as it raged, whip it to fury and scour Toman Head clean from the sea to the plain. Embrace saidin. He suppressed the longing ruthlessly.

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt. "wʌt? oʊ. aɪ səpoʊz. ə lɪɾəl. aɪ kʊdn stɑp ə stɔɹm ðɪs bɪɡ, nɑt baɪ maɪsɛlf - ɪt kʌvɝz tu mʌtʃ ɛɹiə - bʌɾ aɪ kəd lɛsən ɪt sʌm. wɛɹ wi ɑɹ, ət list." ʃi waɪpt ɹeɪn fɹəm əɹ feɪs, sim tə ɹilaɪz fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm ðəɾ əɹ hʊd hæd slɪpt, ən pʊld ɪt bæk ʌp æbsənli.

The Aes Sedai gave a start. "What? Oh. I suppose. A little. I couldn't stop a storm this big, not by myself - it covers too much area - but I could lessen it some. Where we are, at least." She wiped rain from her face, seemed to realize for the first time that her hood had slipped, and pulled it back up absently.

"ðɛn waɪ doʊn ju?" mæt sɛd. ðə ʃɪvɝɪŋ feɪs piɹɪŋ aʊt fɹəm ʌndɝ ɪz hʊd lʊkt ət dɛθs dɔɹ, bʌɾ ɪz vɔɪs wɑz vɪɡɝəs.

"Then why don't you?" Mat said. The shivering face peering out from under his hood looked at death's door, but his voice was vigorous.

"bɪkɔz ɪf aɪ juz ðət mʌtʃ ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ, ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ kloʊsɝ ðən tɛn maɪlz wəd noʊ sʌmwʌn hæd tʃænəld. wi doʊnt wɑnə bɹɪŋ ðiz sintʃæn daʊn ɑn əs wɪð səm ə ðɛɹ deɪmeɪn." hɝ maʊθ taɪɾənd æŋɡɹəli.

"Because if I used that much of the One Power, any Aes Sedai closer than ten miles would know someone had channeled. We don't want to bring these Seanchan down on us with some of their damane." Her mouth tightened angrily.

ðeɪ hæd lɝn ə lɪɾəl ə ði ɪnveɪɾɝz ɪn ðət vɪlədʒ, kɔld əɾəənz mɪl, ðoʊ moʊst ʌv wʌt ðeɪ hæd hɝd hætʃt mɔɹ kwɛstʃənz ðən ɪɾ ænsɝd. ðə pipəl hæd bæbəld wʌn moʊmən ən klæmp ðɛɹ maʊðz ʃʌt ðə nɛkst, tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ ən lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz. ðeɪ ɔl ʃʊk wɪð fɪɹ ðət ðə sintʃæn wəd ɹɪtɝn wɪð ðɛɹ mɑnstɝz ən ðɛɹ deɪmeɪn. ðət wɪmən u ʃʊɾə bɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ ɪnstɛd liʃt laɪk ænəməlz fɹaɪɾənd ðə vɪlɪdʒɝz ivən mɔɹ ðən ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ kɹitʃɝz ðə sintʃæn kəmændəd, θɪŋz ðə foʊk ʌv əɾəənz mɪl kəɾ oʊnli dɪskɹaɪb ɪn wɪspɝz əz kʌmɪŋ fɹəm naɪtmɛɹz. ən wɝst ʌv ɔl, ði ɪɡzæmpəlz ðə sintʃæn hæd meɪd bɪfɔɹ livɪŋ stɪl tʃɪl ðə pipəl tə ðɛɹ mɛɹoʊ. ðeɪ hæd bɛɹid ðɛɹ dɛd, bʌt ðeɪ fɪɹd tə klin əweɪ ðə lɑɹdʒ tʃɑɹd pætʃ ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ skwɛɹ. nʌn ə ðɛm wəd seɪ wʌt hæd hæpən ðɛɹ, bʌt hʊɹɪn hæd vɑməɾəd əz sun əz ðeɪ ɛntɝd ðə vɪlədʒ, ən i wəd nɑt ɡoʊ nɪɹ ðə blækənd ɡɹaʊnd.

They had learned a little of the invaders in that village, called Atuan's Mill, though most of what they had heard hatched more questions than it answered. The people had babbled one moment and clamped their mouths shut the next, trembling and looking over their shoulders. They all shook with fear that the Seanchan would return with their monsters and their damane. That women who should have been Aes Sedai were instead leashed like animals frightened the villagers even more than the strange creatures the Seanchan commanded, things the folk of Atuan's Mill could only describe in whispers as coming from nightmares. And worst of all, the examples the Seanchan had made before leaving still chilled the people to their marrow. They had buried their dead, but they feared to clean away the large charred patch in the village square. None of them would say what had happened there, but Hurin had vomited as soon as they entered the village, and he would not go near the blackened ground.

əɾəənz mɪl hæd bɪn hæf dɪzɝɾɪd. səm hæd flɛd tə fɑlm, θɪŋkɪŋ ðə sintʃæn wəd nɑt bi soʊ hɑɹʃ ɪn ə taʊn ðeɪ hɛl fæst, ən ʌðɝz hæd ɡɔn ist. mɔɹ hæd sɛd ðeɪ wɝ θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv ɪt. ðəɹ wɑz faɪɾɪŋ ɑn ɑlməθ pleɪn, tæɹɑbənɝz bæɾəlɪŋ dəmɑni ɪt wɑz sɛd, bʌt sətʃ haʊsəz ən bɑɹnz əz wɝ bɝn ðəɹ wɝ kɪndəl baɪ tɔɹtʃɪz ɪn ðə hænz ə mɛn. ivən ə wɔɹ wɑz iziɝ tə feɪs ðən wʌt ðə sintʃæn hæd dʌn, wʌt ðeɪ maɪt du.

Atuan's Mill had been half deserted. Some had fled to Falme, thinking the Seanchan would not be so harsh in a town they held fast, and others had gone east. More had said they were thinking of it. There was fighting on Almoth Plain, Taraboners battling Domani it was said, but such houses and barns as were burned there were kindled by torches in the hands of men. Even a war was easier to face than what the Seanchan had done, what they might do.

"waɪ dɪd feɪn bɹɪŋ ðə hɔɹn hɪɹ?" pɛɹɪn mʌɾɝd. ðə kwɛstʃən hæd bɪn æsk baɪ itʃ ə ðɛm ət wʌn taɪm əɹ ənʌðɝ, ən noʊ wʌn hæɾ ən ænsɝ. "ðɛɹz wɔɹ, ən ðiz sintʃæn, ən ðɛɹ mɑnstɝz. waɪ hɪɹ?"

"Why did Fain bring the Horn here?" Perrin muttered. The question had been asked by each of them at one time or another, and no one had an answer. "There's war, and these Seanchan, and their monsters. Why here?"

ɪŋtʃɹ tɝn ɪn ɪz sæɾəl tə lʊk bæk ət ðɛm. hɪz feɪs əpɪɹɾ ɔlmoʊst əz hæɡɝɾ əz mæts. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ ɔlweɪz mɛn u si tʃænsəz fəɹ ðɛɹ oʊn ædvæntɪdʒ ɪn ðə kənfjuʒən ʌv wɔɹ. feɪn ɪz wʌn laɪk ðæt. noʊ daʊɾ i θɪŋks tə stil ðə hɔɹn əɡɛn, fɹəm ðə dɑɹk wʌn ðɪs taɪm, ən juz ɪt fəɹ ɪz oʊn pɹɑfət."

Ingtar turned in his saddle to look back at them. His face appeared almost as haggard as Mat's. "There are always men who see chances for their own advantage in the confusion of war. Fain is one like that. No doubt he thinks to steal the Horn again, from the Dark One this time, and use it for his own profit."

"ðə fɑðɝ ə laɪz nɛvɝ leɪz sɪmpəl plænz," vɛɹɪn sɛd. "ɪt meɪ bi ðəɾ i wɑns feɪn tə bɹɪŋ ðə hɔɹn hɪɹ fəɹ səm ɹizən noʊn oʊnli ɪn ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl."

"The Father of Lies never lays simple plans," Verin said. "It may be that he wants Fain to bring the Horn here for some reason known only in Shayol Ghul."

"mɑnstɝz," mæt snɔɹɾɪd. hɪz tʃiks wɝ sʌŋkən, naʊ, hɪz aɪz hɑloʊ. ðəɾ i saʊndəd hɛlθi oʊnli meɪɾ ɪt wɝs. "ðeɪ sɔ səm tʃɹɑləks, əɹ ə feɪd, ɪf jə æsk mi. wɛl, waɪ nɑt? ɪf ðə sintʃæn əv ɛɛs sədaɪ faɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ðɛm, waɪ nɑt feɪdz ən tʃɹɑləks?" hi kɑt vɛɹɪn stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪm ən flɪntʃt. "wɛl, ðeɪ ɑɹ, ɑn liʃɪz əɹ nɑt. ðeɪ kən tʃænəl, ən ðət meɪks əm ɛɛs sədaɪ." hi ɡlænst ət ɹænd ən ɡeɪv ə ɹæɡəd læf. "ðæt meɪks jə ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðə laɪt hɛlp əs ɔl."

"Monsters," Mat snorted. His cheeks were sunken, now, his eyes hollow. That he sounded healthy only made it worse. "They saw some Trollocs, or a Fade, if you ask me. Well, why not? If the Seanchan have Aes Sedai fighting for them, why not Fades and Trollocs?" He caught Verin staring at him and flinched. "Well, they are, on leashes or not. They can channel, and that makes them Aes Sedai." He glanced at Rand and gave a ragged laugh. "That makes you Aes Sedai, the Light help us all."

mæsimə keɪm ɡæləpɪŋ fɹəm əhɛd, θɹu ðə mʌɾ ən ðə stɛɾi ɹeɪn. "ðɛɹ ɪz ənʌðɝ vɪlədʒ əhɛd, maɪ lɔɹd," hi sɛɾ əz i pʊld ɪn bɪsaɪɾ ɪŋtʃɹ. hɪz aɪz oʊnli swɛpt pæst ɹænd, bʌt ðeɪ taɪɾənd, ən i dɪd nɑt lʊk ət ɹænd əɡɛn. "ɪts ɛmpti, maɪ lɔɹd. noʊ vɪlɪdʒɝz, noʊ sintʃæn, noʊbɑdi əɾ ɔl. ðə haʊsəz ɔl lʊk saʊnd, ðoʊ, ɪksɛp fəɹ tu əɹ θɹi ðət . . . wɛl, ðeɪ ɑɹən ðəɹ ɛnimɔɹ, maɪ lɔɹd."

Masema came galloping from ahead, through the mud and the steady rain. "There is another village ahead, my Lord," he said as he pulled in beside Ingtar. His eyes only swept past Rand, but they tightened, and he did not look at Rand again. "It's empty, my Lord. No villagers, no Seanchan, nobody at all. The houses all look sound, though, except for two or three that . . . well, they aren't there anymore, my Lord."

ɪŋtʃɹ ɹeɪzd ɪz hæn ən sɪɡnəl fəɹ ə tʃɹɑt.

Ingtar raised his hand and signaled for a trot.

ðə vɪlədʒ mæsimə hæd faʊn kʌvɝd ðə sloʊps ʌv ə hɪl, wɪð ə peɪv skwɛɹ ət ðə tɑp ɝaʊn ə sɝkəl ə stoʊn wɔlz. ðə haʊsəz wɝ ə stoʊn, ɔl flæt-ɹuft ən fju mɔɹ ðən ə sɪŋɡəl stɔɹi. θɹi ðət hæd bɪn lɑɹdʒɝ, əlɔŋ wʌn saɪɾ ə ðə skwɛɹ, wɝ oʊnli hips ə blækən ɹʌbəl; ʃæɾɝd tʃʌŋks ə stoʊn ən ɹuf bimz leɪ skæɾɝd əkɹɔs ðə skwɛɹ. ə fju ʃʌɾɝz bæŋd wən ðə wɪnd ɡʌstɪd.

The village Masema had found covered the slopes of a hill, with a paved square at the top around a circle of stone walls. The houses were of stone, all flat-roofed and few more than a single story. Three that had been larger, along one side of the square, were only heaps of blackened rubble; shattered chunks of stone and roof beams lay scattered across the square. A few shutters banged when the wind gusted.

ɪŋtʃɹ dɪsmaʊntɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ði oʊnli lɑɹdʒ bɪldɪŋ stɪl stændɪŋ. ðə kɹikɪŋ saɪn əbʌv ɪts dɔɹ bɔɹ ə wʊmən dʒʌɡəlɪŋ stɑɹz, bʌt noʊ neɪm; ɹeɪn keɪm ɔf ðə kɔɹnɝz ɪn tu stɛɾi dʒɹɪzəlz. vɛɹɪn hɝiɾ ɪnsaɪd waɪl ɪŋtʃɹ spoʊk. "ənoʊ, sɝtʃ ɛvɹi haʊs. ɪf ðəɹ ɪz ɛniwʌn lɛft, pɝhæps ðeɪ kən tɛl əs wʌt hæpən hɪɹ, ən meɪbi ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ əbaʊt ðiz sintʃæn. ən ɪf ðɛɹz ɛni fud, bɹɪŋ ðæt, tu. ən blæŋkəts." ənoʊ nɑɾəd ən bɪɡæn tɛlɪŋ ɔf mɛn. ɪŋtʃɹ tɝn tə hʊɹɪn. "wʌt dʒju smɛl? dɪd feɪn kʌm θɹu hɪɹ?"

Ingtar dismounted in front of the only large building still standing. The creaking sign above its door bore a woman juggling stars, but no name; rain came off the corners in two steady drizzles. Verin hurried inside while Ingtar spoke. "Uno, search every house. If there is anyone left, perhaps they can tell us what happened here, and maybe a little more about these Seanchan. And if there's any food, bring that, too. And blankets." Uno nodded and began telling off men. Ingtar turned to Hurin. "What do you smell? Did Fain come through here?"

hʊɹɪn, ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz noʊz, ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "nɑt hɪm, maɪ lɔɹd, ən nɑt ðə tʃɹɑləks, niðɝ. huɛvɝ dɪd ðət lɛft ə stɛntʃ, ðoʊ." hi pɔɪntəd tə ðə ɹɛkədʒ ðət hæd bɪn haʊzɪz. "ɪt wɑz kɪlɪŋ, maɪ lɔɹd. ðəɹ wɝ pipəl ɪn ðɛɹ."

Hurin, rubbing his nose, shook his head. "Not him, my Lord, and not the Trollocs, neither. Whoever did that left a stench, though." He pointed to the wreckage that had been houses. "It was killing, my Lord. There were people in there."

"sintʃæn," ɪŋtʃɹ ɡɹaʊld. "lɛts ɡɛɾ ɪnsaɪd. ɹeɪɡən, faɪn səm sɔɹɾ ə steɪbəl fəɹ ðə hɔɹsəz."

"Seanchan," Ingtar growled. "Let's get inside. Ragan, find some sort of stable for the horses."

vɛɹɪn ɔlɹɛɾi hæd faɪɝz ɡoʊɪŋ ɪn boʊθ ə ðə bɪɡ faɪɝpleɪsəz, əɾ iðɝ ɛn ə ðə kɑmən ɹum, ən wɑz wɔɹmɪŋ əɹ hænz ət wʌn, hɝ sɑɾən kloʊk spɹɛɾ aʊɾ ɑn wʌn ə ðə teɪbəlz dɑɾɪŋ ðə taɪl flɔɹ. ʃi hæd faʊn ə fju kændəlz, tu, naʊ bɝnɪŋ ɑn ə teɪbəl stʌk ɪn ðɛɹ oʊn tæloʊ. ɛmptinəs ən kwaɪət, ɪksɛp fəɹ ði əkeɪʒənəl ɡɹʌmbəl ə θʌndɝ, æɾəd tə ðə flɪkɝɪŋ ʃædoʊz tə ɡɪv ðə pleɪs ə kævɝnəs fil. ɹænd tɔst ɪz ikwəli wɛt kloʊk ən koʊɾ ɑn ə teɪbəl ən dʒɔɪn hɝ. oʊnli lɔɪəl simd mɔɹ ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn tʃɛkɪŋ ɪz bʊks ðən ɪn wɔɹmɪŋ hɪmsɛlf.

Verin already had fires going in both of the big fireplaces, at either end of the common room, and was warming her hands at one, her sodden cloak spread out on one of the tables dotting the tiled floor. She had found a few candles, too, now burning on a table stuck in their own tallow. Emptiness and quiet, except for the occasional grumble of thunder, added to the flickering shadows to give the place a cavernous feel. Rand tossed his equally wet cloak and coat on a table and joined her. Only Loial seemed more interested in checking his books than in warming himself.

"wi wɪl nɛvɝ faɪn ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ ðɪs weɪ," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd. "θɹi deɪz sɪns wi . . . sɪns wi ɝaɪv hɪɹ" - hi ʃʌɾɝəd ən skɹʌbd ə hæn θɹu hɪz hɛɹ; ɹænd wʌndɝd wʌt ðə ʃaɪnɝən hæd sin ɪn ɪz ʌðɝ lɪvz - "ənʌðɝ tu, ət list, tə fɑlm, ən wɪv nɑt faʊn soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə hɛɹ ə feɪn əɹ dɑɹkfɹɛnz. ðəɹ ɑɹ skɔɹz ə vɪlədʒəz əlɔŋ ðə koʊst. hi cʊɾə ɡɔn tə ɛni ʌv əm ən teɪkən ʃɪp ɛniwɛɹ baɪ naʊ. ɪf i wɑz ɛvɝ hɪɹ."

"We will never find the Horn of Valere this way," Ingtar said. "Three days since we . . . since we arrived here" - he shuddered and scrubbed a hand through his hair; Rand wondered what the Shienaran had seen in his other lives - "another two, at least, to Falme, and we have not found so much as a hair of Fain or Darkfriends. There are scores of villages along the coast. He could have gone to any of them and taken ship anywhere by now. If he was ever here."

"hi ɪz hɪɹ," vɛɹɪn sɛd kɑmli, "æn i wɛn tə fɑlm."

"He is here," Verin said calmly, "and he went to Falme."

"æn hiz stɪl hɪɹ," ɹænd sɛd. weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ mi. pliz, laɪt, hiz stɪl weɪɾɪŋ.

"And he's still here," Rand said. Waiting for me. Please, Light, he's still waiting.

"hʊɹɪn stɪl hæzən kɑɾ ə wɪf ə hɪm," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd. ðə snɪfɝ ʃɹʌɡd əz ɪf i fɛl hɪmsɛlf ət fɔl fəɹ ðə feɪljɝ. "waɪ wəɾ i tʃuz fɑlm? ɪf ðoʊz vɪlɪdʒɝz ɑɹ tə bi bɪlivd, fɑlm ɪz hɛl baɪ ðiz sintʃæn. aɪ wəd ɡɪv maɪ bɛs haʊn tə noʊ hu ðeɪ ɑɹ, ən wɛɹ ðeɪ keɪm fɹʌm."

"Hurin still hasn't caught a whiff of him," Ingtar said. The sniffer shrugged as if he felt himself at fault for the failure. "Why would he choose Falme? If those villagers are to be believed, Falme is held by these Seanchan. I would give my best hound to know who they are, and where they came from."

"hu ðeɪ ɑɹ ɪz nɑɾ ɪmpɔɹɾənt tə ʌs." vɛɹɪn nɛlt ən ənfæsən əɹ sæɾəlbæɡz, pʊlɪŋ aʊt dʒɹaɪ kloʊðz. "æt list wɪv ɹumz ɪn wɪtʃ tə tʃeɪnʒ əɹ kloʊðz, ðoʊ ɪɾəl də əs lɪɾəl ɡʊɾ ənlɛs ðə wɛðɝ tʃeɪnʒəz. ɪŋtʃɹ, ɪt meɪ wɛl bi ðət wʌt ðə vɪlɪdʒɝz toʊld əs ɪz ɹaɪt, ðət ðeɪ ɑɹ ðə dɪsɛndəns ʌv ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz ɑɹmiz kʌm bæk. wʌt mæɾɝz ɪz ðət pdən feɪn əz ɡɔn tə fɑlm. ðə ɹaɪɾɪŋz ɪn ðə dʌnʒən ət fæl dæɹə - "

"Who they are is not important to us." Verin knelt and unfastened her saddlebags, pulling out dry clothes. "At least we have rooms in which to change our clothes, though it will do us little good unless the weather changes. Ingtar, it may well be that what the villagers told us is right, that they are the descendants of Artur Hawkwing's armies come back. What matters is that Padan Fain has gone to Falme. The writings in the dungeon at Fal Dara - "

" - nɛvɝ mɛnʃən feɪn. fɝɡɪv mi, ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌt ðət cʊɾə bɪn ə tʃɹɪk əz izəli əz dɑɹk pɹɑfəsi. aɪ kæn bɪliv ivən tʃɹɑləks wəd bi stupəɾ ɪnʌf tə tɛl əs ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðeɪ wɝ gɑnə də bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ dɪɾ ɪt."

" - never mentioned Fain. Forgive me, Aes Sedai, but that could have been a trick as easily as dark prophecy. I can't believe even Trollocs would be stupid enough to tell us everything they were going to do before they did it."

ʃi twɪstəd tə lʊk ʌp ət hɪm. "ænd wʌt dʒju min tə du, ɪf jəl nɑt teɪk maɪ ædvaɪs?"

She twisted to look up at him. "And what do you mean to do, if you will not take my advice?"

"aɪ min tə hæv ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd fɝmli. "fɝɡɪv mi, bʌɾ aɪ hæv tə tʃɹʌs maɪ oʊn sɛnsɪz bɪfɔɹ səm wɝdz skɹɔl baɪ ə tʃɹɑlɑk . . ."

"I mean to have the Horn of Valere," Ingtar said firmly. "Forgive me, but I have to trust my own senses before some words scrawled by a Trolloc . . ."

"eɪ mɹdʒɹɑl, ʃʊɹli," vɛɹɪn mɝmɝd, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑɾ ivən pɔz.

"A Myrddraal, surely," Verin murmured, but he did not even pause.

". . . əɹ ə dɑɹkfɹɛn simɪŋ tə bɪtʃɹeɪ hɪmsɛlf aʊɾ ə hɪz oʊn maʊθ. aɪ min tə kɔɹɾɝ ðə ɡɹaʊn əntɪl hʊɹɪn smɛlz ə tʃɹeɪl əɹ wi faɪn feɪn ɪn ðə flɛʃ. aɪ mʌst əv ðə hɔɹn, vɛɹɪn sədaɪ. aɪ mʌst!"

". . . or a Darkfriend seeming to betray himself out of his own mouth. I mean to quarter the ground until Hurin smells a trail or we find Fain in the flesh. I must have the Horn, Verin Sedai. I must!"

"ðæɾ ɪzən ðə weɪ," hʊɹɪn sɛd sɔfli. "nɑt 'mʌst.' wʌt hæpənz, hæpənz." noʊ wʌn peɪɾ ɪm ɛni maɪnd.

"That isn't the way," Hurin said softly. "Not 'must.' What happens, happens." No one paid him any mind.

"wi ɔl mʌst," vɛɹɪn mɝmɝd, piɹɪŋ ɪndə hɝ sæɾəlbæɡz, "jɛt səm θɪŋz meɪ bi ivən mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðən ðæt."

"We all must," Verin murmured, peering into her saddlebags, "yet some things may be even more important than that."

ʃi dɪd nɑt seɪ mɔɹ, bʌt ɹænd ɡɹɪməst. hi lɔŋ tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ fɹəm əɹ ən əɹ pɹɑdz ən hɪns. aɪm nɑt ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. laɪt, bʌɾ aɪ wɪʃ aɪ kəd dʒʌst ɡɛɾ əweɪ fɹəm ɛɛs sədaɪ kəmplitli. "ɪŋtʃɹ, aɪ θɪŋk aɪm ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɑn tə fɑlm. feɪn ɪz ðəɹ - ɪm ʃʊɹ hiz - ən ɪf aɪ doʊn kʌm sun, hi - hɪl də sʌmθɪŋ tə hɝɾ ɛmənz fild." hi hæd nɑt mɛnʃən ðət pɑɹt bɪfɔɹ.

She did not say more, but Rand grimaced. He longed to get away from her and her prods and hints. I am not the Dragon Reborn. Light, but I wish I could just get away from Aes Sedai completely. "Ingtar, I think I'm riding on to Falme. Fain is there - I'm sure he is - and if I don't come soon, he - he will do something to hurt Emond's Field." He had not mentioned that part before.

ðeɪ ɔl stɛɹɾ ət hɪm, mæt ən pɛɹɪn fɹaʊnɪŋ, wɝid bʌt kənsɪɾɝɪŋ; vɛɹɪn əz ɪf ʃi hæd dʒʌst sin ə nu pis æɾəd tə ə pʌzəl. lɔɪəl lʊkt əstɑnɪʃt, ən hʊɹɪn sim kənfjuzd. ɪŋtʃɹ wɑz oʊpənli dɪsbɪlivɪŋ.

They all stared at him, Mat and Perrin frowning, worried but considering; Verin as if she had just seen a new piece added to a puzzle. Loial looked astonished, and Hurin seemed confused. Ingtar was openly disbelieving.

"waɪ wəɾ i də ðæt?" ðə ʃaɪnɝən sɛd.

"Why would he do that?" the Shienaran said.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ," ɹænd laɪd, "bʌt ðət wɑz pɑɹɾ ə ðə mɛsədʒ i lɛft wɪð bɑɹθeɪnz."

"I don't know," Rand lied, "but that was part of the message he left with Barthanes."

"æn dɪd bɑɹθeɪnz seɪ feɪn wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə fɑlm?" ɪŋtʃɹ dɪmændəd. "noʊ. ɪt wʊdn mæɾɝ ɪf i hæd." hi ɡeɪv ə bɪɾɝ læf. "dɑɹkfɹɛnz laɪ əz nætʃɹəli əz ðeɪ bɹið."

"And did Barthanes say Fain was going to Falme?" Ingtar demanded. "No. It wouldn't matter if he had." He gave a bitter laugh. "Darkfriends lie as naturally as they breathe."

"ɹænd," mæt sɛd, "ɪf aɪ nu haʊ tə stɑp feɪn fɹəm hɝɾɪŋ ɛmənz fild, aɪ wʊd. ɪf aɪ wɑz ʃʊɹ i wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə. bʌɾ aɪ nid ðət dæɡɝ, ɹænd, ən hʊɹɪn əz ðə bɛs tʃæns ə faɪndɪŋ ɪt."

"Rand," Mat said, "if I knew how to stop Fain from hurting Emond's Field, I would. If I was sure he was going to. But I need that dagger, Rand, and Hurin has the best chance of finding it."

"aɪ wɪl ɡoʊ wɛɹɛvɝ jə ɡoʊ, ɹænd," lɔɪəl sɛd. hi hæd fɪnɪʃt meɪkɪŋ ʃʊɹ ðə bʊks wɝ dʒɹaɪ ən wɑz teɪkɪŋ ɔf ɪz sɑɾən koʊt. "bʌɾ aɪ doʊn si wɛɹ ə fju mɔɹ deɪz wɪl tʃeɪnʒ ɛniθɪŋ wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ, naʊ. tʃɹaɪ biɪŋ ə lɪɾəl lɛs heɪsti fəɹ wʌns."

"I will go wherever you go, Rand," Loial said. He had finished making sure the books were dry and was taking off his sodden coat. "But I don't see where a few more days will change anything one way or another, now. Try being a little less hasty for once."

"ɪt dʌzn mæɾɝ tə mi wɛðɝ wi ɡoʊ tə fɑlm naʊ, leɪɾɝ, əɹ nɛvɝ," pɛɹɪn sɛd wɪð ə ʃɹʌɡ, "bʌɾ ɪf feɪn ɹɪli ɪz θɹɛɾənɪŋ ɛmənz fild . . . wɛl, mæts ɹaɪt. hʊɹɪn ɪz ðə bɛst weɪ tə faɪn hɪm."

"It doesn't matter to me whether we go to Falme now, later, or never," Perrin said with a shrug, "but if Fain really is threatening Emond's Field . . . well, Mat's right. Hurin is the best way to find him."

"aɪ kən faɪn hɪm, lɔɹd ɹænd," hʊɹɪn pʊɾ ɪn. "lɛt mi ɡɛt wʌn snɪf ə hɪm, ən əl teɪk jə ɹaɪt tə hɪm. ðɛɹz nɛvɝ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls lɛft ə tʃɹeɪl laɪk hɪz."

"I can find him, Lord Rand," Hurin put in. "Let me get one sniff of him, and I'll take you right to him. There's never anything else left a trail like his."

"ju mʌs meɪk jəɹ oʊn tʃɔɪs, ɹænd," vɛɹɪn sɛd kɛɹfəli, "bʌt ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðət fɑlm ɪz hɛl baɪ ɪnveɪɾɝz əbaʊt hum wi stɪl noʊ nɛks tə nʌθɪŋ. ɪf jə ɡoʊ tə fɑlm əloʊn, jə meɪ faɪn jɝsɛlf ə pɹɪznɝ, əɹ wɝs, ən ðət wɪl sɝv nʌθɪŋ. aɪm ʃʊɹ wʌtɛvɝ tʃɔɪs jə meɪk wɪl bi ðə ɹaɪt wʌn."

"You must make your own choice, Rand," Verin said carefully, "but remember that Falme is held by invaders about whom we still know next to nothing. If you go to Falme alone, you may find yourself a prisoner, or worse, and that will serve nothing. I am sure whatever choice you make will be the right one."

"tɑvɝən," lɔɪəl ɹʌmbəld.

"Ta'veren," Loial rumbled.

ɹænd θɹu ʌp ɪz hænz.

Rand threw up his hands.

ənoʊ keɪm ɪn fɹəm ðə skwɛɹ, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɹeɪn ɔf ɪz kloʊk.

Uno came in from the square, shaking rain off his cloak.

"nɑɾ ə fleɪmɪŋ soʊl tə bi faʊnd, maɪ lɔɹd. lʊks tə mi laɪk ðeɪ ɹæn laɪk stʃɹaɪpt pɪɡz. laɪvstɑks ɔl ɡɔn, ən ðəɹ ɪzən ə blʌɾi kɑɹɾ əɹ wæɡən lɛft, iðɝ. hæf ðə haʊsəz ɑɹ stʃɹɪp tə ðə fleɪmɪŋ flɔɹz. əl weɪdʒɝ maɪ nɛks mʌnθs peɪ jə kəd fɑloʊ ðɛm baɪ ðə blʌɾi fɝnɪtʃɝ ðeɪ tɔst ɑn ðə saɪɾ ə ðə ɹoʊd wən ðeɪ ɹilaɪzd ɪt wɑz oʊnli weɪɪŋ daʊn ðɛɹ fleɪmɪŋ wæɡənz."

"Not a flaming soul to be found, my Lord. Looks to me like they ran like striped pigs. Livestock's all gone, and there isn't a bloody cart or wagon left, either. Half the houses are stripped to the flaming floors. I'll wager my next month's pay you could follow them by the bloody furniture they tossed on the side of the road when they realized it was only weighing down their flaming wagons."

"wʌɾ əbaʊt kloʊðz?" ɪŋtʃɹ æskt.

"What about clothes?" Ingtar asked.

ənoʊ blɪŋkt ɪz wʌn aɪ ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. "dʒʌst ə fju bɪts ən pisəz, maɪ lɔɹd. meɪnli wʌt ðeɪ dɪdn θɪŋk wɑz blʌɾi wɝθ teɪkɪŋ wɪð ðɛm."

Uno blinked his one eye in surprise. "Just a few bits and pieces, my Lord. Mainly what they didn't think was bloody worth taking with them."

"ðeɪ wɪl əv tə du. hʊɹɪn, aɪ min tə dʒɹɛs jə ən ə fju mɔɹ əz loʊkəl pipəl, əz mɛni əz wi kən mænədʒ, soʊ jə woʊn stæn aʊt. aɪ wɑn jə tə swɪŋ waɪd, nɔɹθ ən saʊθ, əntɪl jə kɹɔs ðə tʃɹeɪl." mɔɹ soʊlʒɝz wɝ kʌmɪŋ ɪn, ən ðeɪ ɔl ɡæðɝɾ ɝaʊn ɪŋtʃɹ ən hʊɹɪn tə lɪsən.

"They will have to do. Hurin, I mean to dress you and a few more as local people, as many as we can manage, so you won't stand out. I want you to swing wide, north and south, until you cross the trail." More soldiers were coming in, and they all gathered around Ingtar and Hurin to listen.

ɹænd lin ɪz hænz ɑn ðə mæntəl oʊvɝ ðə faɪɝpleɪs ən stɛɹɾ ɪndə ðə fleɪmz. ðeɪ meɪɾ ɪm θɪŋk ə bælzəmənz aɪz. "ðɛɹ ɪzən mʌtʃ taɪm," hi sɛd. "aɪ fil . . . sʌmθɪŋ . . . pʊlɪŋ mi tə fɑlm, ən ðəɹ ɪzən mʌtʃ taɪm." hi sɔ vɛɹɪn wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm, ən æɾəd hɑɹʃli, "nɑt ðæt. ɪts feɪn aɪ hæv tə faɪnd. ɪts nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð . . . ðæt."

Rand leaned his hands on the mantel over the fireplace and stared into the flames. They made him think of Ba'alzamon's eyes. "There isn't much time," he said. "I feel . . . something . . . pulling me to Falme, and there isn't much time." He saw Verin watching him, and added harshly, "Not that. It's Fain I have to find. It has nothing to do with . . . that."

vɛɹɪn nɑɾəd. "ðə wil wivz əz ðə wil wɪlz, ən wəɹ ɔl woʊvən ɪndə ðə pæɾɝn. feɪn əz bɪn hɪɹ wiks bɪfɔɹ ʌs, pɝhæps mʌnθs. ə fju mɔɹ deɪz wɪl meɪk lɪɾəl dɪfɝəns ɪn wʌtɛvɝ ɪz ɡoʊɪŋ tə hæpən."

Verin nodded. "The Wheel weaves as the Wheel wills, and we are all woven into the Pattern. Fain has been here weeks before us, perhaps months. A few more days will make little difference in whatever is going to happen."

"aɪm gɑnə ɡɛt səm slip," hi mʌɾɝd, pɪkɪŋ ʌp ɪz sæɾəlbæɡz. "ðeɪ kæn əv kæɹiɾ ɔf ɔl ðə bɛdz."

"I'm going to get some sleep," he muttered, picking up his saddlebags. "They can't have carried off all the beds."

əpstɛɹz, hi dɪd faɪn bɛdz, bʌɾ oʊnli ə fju stɪl hæd mætʃɹəsəz, ən ðoʊz soʊ lʌmpi hi θɔɾ ɪt maɪt bi mɔɹ kʌmftəɹbəl tə slip ɑn ðə flɔɹ. faɪnəli hi tʃoʊz ə bɛd wɛɹ ðə mætʃɹəs sɪmpli sæɡd ɪn ðə mɪɾəl. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ ɛls ɪn ðə ɹum ɪksɛpt wʌn wʊɾən tʃɛɹ ən ə teɪbəl wɪð ə ɹɪkəɾi lɛɡ.

Upstairs, he did find beds, but only a few still had mattresses, and those so lumpy he thought it might be more comfortable to sleep on the floor. Finally he chose a bed where the mattress simply sagged in the middle. There was nothing else in the room except one wooden chair and a table with a rickety leg.

hi tʊk ɔf ɪz wɛt θɪŋz, pʊɾɪŋ ɑn ə dʒɹaɪ ʃɝɾ ən bɹitʃɪz bɪfɔɹ laɪɪŋ daʊn, sɪns ðəɹ wɝ noʊ ʃits əɹ blæŋkəts, ən pɹɑpt ɪz sɔɹd bɪsaɪd ðə hɛɾ ə ðə bɛd. ɹaɪli, hi θɔt ðət ði oʊnli θɪŋ dʒɹaɪ hi hæd fəɹ ə kʌvɝlət wɑz ðə dʒɹæɡənz bænɝ; hi lɛft ɪt seɪfli bʌkəld ɪnsaɪd ðə sæɾəlbæɡz.

He took off his wet things, putting on a dry shirt and breeches before lying down, since there were no sheets or blankets, and propped his sword beside the head of the bed. Wryly, he thought that the only thing dry he had for a coverlet was the Dragon's banner; he left it safely buckled inside the saddlebags.

ɹeɪn dʒɹʌmd ɑn ðə ɹuf, ən θʌndɝ ɡɹaʊld oʊvɝhɛd, ən naʊ ən əɡɛn ə laɪtnɪŋ flæʃ lɪt ðə wɪndoʊz. ʃɪvɝɪŋ, hi ɹoʊl ðɪs weɪ ən ðəɾ ɑn ðə mætʃɹəs, sikɪŋ səm kʌmftəɹbəl weɪ tə laɪ, wʌndɝɪŋ ɪf ðə bænɝ wəd nɑt də fəɹ ə blæŋkəɾ æftɝ ɔl, wʌndɝɪŋ ɪf i ʃəd ɹaɪɾ ɑn tə fɑlm.

Rain drummed on the roof, and thunder growled overhead, and now and again a lightning flash lit the windows. Shivering, he rolled this way and that on the mattress, seeking some comfortable way to lie, wondering if the banner would not do for a blanket after all, wondering if he should ride on to Falme.

hi ɹoʊl tə hɪz ʌðɝ saɪd, ən bælzəmən wɑz stændɪŋ bɪsaɪd ðə tʃɛɹ wɪð ðə pjʊɹ waɪt lɛŋθ ə ðə dʒɹæɡənz bænɝ ɪn ɪz hænz. ðə ɹum sim dɑɹkɝ ðɛɹ, əz ɪf bælzəmən stʊɾ ɑn ði ɛdʒ ʌv ə klaʊɾ ʌv ɔɪli blæk smoʊk. nɪɹli hil bɝnz kɹɪskɹɔst ɪz feɪs, ən əz ɹænd lʊkt, hɪz pɪtʃ-dɑɹk aɪz vænɪʃt fəɹ ən ɪnstənt, ɹipleɪs baɪ ɛnləs kævɝnz ə faɪɝ. ɹændz sæɾəlbæɡz leɪ baɪ hɪz fit, bʌkəlz əndʌn, flæp θɹoʊn bæk wɛɹ ðə bænɝ hæd bɪn hɪɾən.

He rolled to his other side, and Ba'alzamon was standing beside the chair with the pure white length of the Dragon's banner in his hands. The room seemed darker there, as if Ba'alzamon stood on the edge of a cloud of oily black smoke. Nearly healed burns crisscrossed his face, and as Rand looked, his pitch-dark eyes vanished for an instant, replaced by endless caverns of fire. Rand's saddlebags lay by his feet, buckles undone, flap thrown back where the banner had been hidden.

"ðə taɪm kʌmz kloʊsɝ, luz θɝɪn. ə θaʊzən θɹɛdz dʒɹɔ taɪt, ən sun jəl bi taɪɾ ən tʃɹæpt, sɛt tə ə kɔɹs jə kænɑt tʃeɪnʒ. mædnəs. dɛθ. bɪfɔɹ jə daɪ, wɪl jə wʌns mɔɹ kɪl ɛvɹiθɪŋ jə lʌv?"

"The time comes closer, Lews Therin. A thousand threads draw tight, and soon you will be tied and trapped, set to a course you cannot change. Madness. Death. Before you die, will you once more kill everything you love?"

ɹænd ɡlænst ət ðə dɔɹ, bʌɾ i meɪd noʊ muv ɪksɛp tə sɪɾ ʌp ɑn ðə saɪɾ ə ðə bɛd. wʌt ɡʊd tə tʃɹaɪ ɹʌnɪŋ fɹəm ðə dɑɹk wʌn? hɪz θɹoʊt fɛlt laɪk sænd. "aɪ æm nɑt ðə dʒɹæɡən, fɑðɝ ə laɪz!" hi sɛd hɔɹsli.

Rand glanced at the door, but he made no move except to sit up on the side of the bed. What good to try running from the Dark One? His throat felt like sand. "I am not the Dragon, Father of Lies!" he said hoarsely.

ðə dɑɹknəs bɪhaɪn bælzəmən ɹɔɪld, ən fɝnəsəz ɹɔɹɾ əz bælzəmən læft. "ju ɑnɝ mi. ən bɪlɪɾəl jɝsɛlf. aɪ noʊ jə tu wɛl. aɪ hæv feɪs jə ə θaʊzən taɪmz. ə θaʊzən taɪmz ə θaʊzənd. aɪ noʊ jə tə jəɹ mɪzɝəbəl soʊl, luz θɝɪn kɪnsleɪɝ." hi læft əɡɛn; ɹænd pʊɾ ə hæn ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪz feɪs əɡɛns ðə hiɾ ə ðət faɪɝi maʊθ.

The darkness behind Ba'alzamon roiled, and furnaces roared as Ba'alzamon laughed. "You honor me. And belittle yourself. I know you too well. I have faced you a thousand times. A thousand times a thousand. I know you to your miserable soul, Lews Therin Kinslayer." He laughed again; Rand put a hand in front of his face against the heat of that fiery mouth.

"wʌt dʒju wɑnt? əl nɑt sɝv ju. əl nɑt də ɛniθɪŋ ðət jə wɑnt. əl daɪ fɝst!"

"What do you want? I will not serve you. I will not do anything that you want. I'll die first!"

"ju wɪl daɪ, wɝm! haʊ mɛni taɪmz əv jə daɪɾ əkɹɔs ðə spæn ə ði eɪdʒəz, ful, ən haʊ mʌtʃ əz dɛθ əveɪl ju? ðə ɡɹeɪv ɪz koʊld ən loʊnli, seɪv fəɹ ðə wɝmz. ðə ɡɹeɪv ɪz maɪn. ðɪs taɪm ðəɹ wɪl bi noʊ ɹibɝθ fəɹ ju. ðɪs taɪm ðə wil ə taɪm wɪl bi bɹoʊkən ən ðə wɝld ɹimeɪɾ ɪn ði ɪmədʒ ə ðə ʃædoʊ. ðɪs taɪm jəɹ dɛθ wɪl bi fɝɛvɝ! wɪtʃ wɪl jə tʃuz? dɛθ ɛvɝlæstɪŋ? əɹ laɪf ɪtɝnəl - ən paʊɝ!"

"You will die, worm! How many times have you died across the span of the Ages, fool, and how much has death availed you? The grave is cold and lonely, save for the worms. The grave is mine. This time there will be no rebirth for you. This time the Wheel of Time will be broken and the world remade in the image of the Shadow. This time your death will be forever! Which will you choose? Death everlasting? Or life eternal - and power!"

ɹænd hɑɹdli ɹilaɪz ðəɾ i wɑz ɑn ɪz fit. ðə vɔɪd hæd sɝaʊndəd hɪm, seɪɾɪn wɑz ðɛɹ, ən ðə wʌn paʊɝ floʊɾ ɪndə hɪm. ðət fækt ɔlmoʊs kɹæk ði ɛmptinəs. wɑz ðɪs ɹil? wɑz ɪɾ ə dʒɹim? kəɾ i tʃænəl ɪn ə dʒɹim? bʌt ðə tɔɹən ɹʌʃɪŋ ɪndə hɪm swɛpt əweɪ hɪz daʊts. hi hɝld ɪɾ ət bælzəmən, hɝl ðə pjʊɹ wʌn paʊɝ, ðə fɔɹs ðət tɝn ðə wil ə taɪm, ə fɔɹs ðət kəd meɪk siz bɝn ən it maʊntənz.

Rand hardly realized that he was on his feet. The void had surrounded him, saidin was there, and the One Power flowed into him. That fact almost cracked the emptiness. Was this real? Was it a dream? Could he channel in a dream? But the torrent rushing into him swept away his doubts. He hurled it at Ba'alzamon, hurled the pure One Power, the force that turned the Wheel of Time, a force that could make seas burn and eat mountains.

bælzəmən tʊk hæf ə stɛp bæk, hoʊldɪŋ ðə bænɝ klʌtʃt bɪfɔɹ hɪm. fleɪmz lɛpt ɪn ɪz waɪɾ aɪz ən maʊθ, ən ðə dɑɹknəs sim tə kloʊk ɪm ɪn ʃædoʊ. ɪn ðə ʃædoʊ. ðə paʊɝ sæŋk ɪndə ðət blæk mɪst ən vænɪʃt, soʊkt ʌp laɪk wɔɾɝ ɑn pɑɹtʃt sænd.

Ba'alzamon took half a step back, holding the banner clutched before him. Flames leaped in his wide eyes and mouth, and the darkness seemed to cloak him in shadow. In the Shadow. The Power sank into that black mist and vanished, soaked up like water on parched sand.

ɹænd dʒɹu ɑn seɪɾɪn, pʊl fəɹ mɔɹ, ən stɪl mɔɹ. hɪz flɛʃ sim soʊ koʊld ɪt mʌst ʃæɾɝ əɾ ə tʌtʃ; ɪt bɝn əz ɪf ɪt mʌs bɔɪl əweɪ. hɪz boʊnz fɛlt ɑn ðə pɔɪn ə kɹɪspɪŋ tə koʊl kɹɪstəl æʃ. hi dɪd nɑt kɛɹ; ɪt wɑz laɪk dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ laɪf ɪtsɛlf.

Rand drew on saidin, pulled for more, and still more. His flesh seemed so cold it must shatter at a touch; it burned as if it must boil away. His bones felt on the point of crisping to cold crystal ash. He did not care; it was like drinking life itself.

"ful!" bælzəmən ɹɔɹd. "ju wɪl dɪstʃɹɔɪ jɝsɛlf!"

"Fool!" Ba'alzamon roared. "You will destroy yourself!"

mæt. ðə θɔt floʊɾəd sʌmwɛɹ bɪɑn ðə kənsumɪŋ flʌd. ðə dæɡɝ. ðə hɔɹn. feɪn. ɛmənz fild. aɪ kæn daɪ jɛt.

Mat. The thought floated somewhere beyond the consuming flood. The dagger. The Horn. Fain. Emond's Field. I can't die yet.

hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ haʊ hi dɪɾ ɪt, bʌt sʌɾənli ðə paʊɝ wɑz ɡɔn, ən seɪɾɪn, ən ðə vɔɪd. ʃʌɾɝɪŋ ʌnkəntʃɹoʊləbli, hi fɛl tə hɪz niz bɪsaɪd ðə bɛd, ɑɹmz ɹæpt ɝaʊn hɪmsɛlf ɪn ə veɪn ɛfɝt tə stɑp ðɛɹ twɪtʃɪŋ.

He was not sure how he did it, but suddenly the Power was gone, and saidin, and the void. Shuddering uncontrollably, he fell to his knees beside the bed, arms wrapped around himself in a vain effort to stop their twitching.

"ðæɾ ɪz bɛɾɝ, luz θɝɪn." bælzəmən tɔs ðə bænɝ tə ðə flɔɹ ən pʊɾ ɪz hænz ɑn ðə tʃɛɹ bæk; wɪsps ə smoʊk ɹoʊz fɹəm bɪtwin ɪz fɪŋɡɝz. ðə ʃædoʊ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɛnkʌmpəs hɪm. "ðɛɹ ɪz jəɹ bænɝ, kɪnsleɪɝ. mʌtʃ ɡʊd wɪl ɪt də ju. ə θaʊzən stʃɹɪŋz leɪɾ oʊvɝ ə θaʊzən jɪɹz əv dʒɹɔn jə hɪɹ. tɛn θaʊzənd woʊvən θɹuaʊt ði eɪdʒəz taɪ jə laɪk ə ʃip fəɹ slɔɾɝ. ðə wil ɪtsɛlf hoʊlz jə pɹɪznɝ tə jəɹ feɪɾ eɪdʒ æftɝ eɪdʒ. bʌɾ aɪ kən sɛt jə fɹi. jə kaʊɝɪŋ kɝ, aɪ əloʊn ɪn ði ɪntaɪɝ wɝl kən titʃ jə haʊ tə wil ðə paʊɝ. aɪ əloʊn kən stɑp ɪt kɪlɪŋ jə bɪfɔɹ juv ə tʃæns tə ɡoʊ mæd. aɪ əloʊn kən stɑp ðə mædnəs. juv sɝv mi bɪfɔɹ. sɝv mi əɡɛn, luz θɝɪn, əɹ bi dɪstʃɹɔɪd fɝɛvɝ!"

"That is better, Lews Therin." Ba'alzamon tossed the banner to the floor and put his hands on the chair back; wisps of smoke rose from between his fingers. The shadow no longer encompassed him. "There is your banner, Kinslayer. Much good will it do you. A thousand strings laid over a thousand years have drawn you here. Ten thousand woven throughout the Ages tie you like a sheep for slaughter. The Wheel itself holds you prisoner to your fate Age after Age. But I can set you free. You cowering cur, I alone in the entire world can teach you how to wield the Power. I alone can stop it killing you before you have a chance to go mad. I alone can stop the madness. You have served me before. Serve me again, Lews Therin, or be destroyed forever!"

"maɪ neɪm," ɹænd fɔɹs bɪtwin tʃæɾɝɪŋ tiθ, "ɪz ɹænd ælθɹ." hɪz ʃɪvɝɪŋ fɔɹst ɪm tə skwiz ɪz aɪz ʃʌt, ən wən i oʊpən əm əɡɛn, hi wɑz əloʊn.

"My name," Rand forced between chattering teeth, "is Rand al'Thor." His shivering forced him to squeeze his eyes shut, and when he opened them again, he was alone.

bælzəmən wɑz ɡɔn. ðə ʃædoʊ wɑz ɡɔn. hɪz sæɾəlbæɡz stʊɾ əɡɛns ðə tʃɛɹ wɪð ðə bʌkəlz dʌn ʌp ən wʌn saɪd bʌlʒɪŋ wɪð ðə bʌlk ə ðə dʒɹæɡənz bænɝ, dʒʌst əz i hæd lɛft ɪt. bʌɾ ɑn ðə tʃɛɹ bæk, tɛnʒɹəlz ə smoʊk stɪl ɹoʊz fɹəm ðə tʃɑɹɾ ɪmpɹɛʃənz ə fɪŋɡɝz.

Ba'alzamon was gone. The shadow was gone. His saddlebags stood against the chair with the buckles done up and one side bulging with the bulk of the Dragon's banner, just as he had left it. But on the chair back, tendrils of smoke still rose from the charred impressions of fingers.


tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾitu


CHAPTER 42

fɑlm


Falme

nɪneɪiv pɹɛst ɪleɪn bæk ɪndə ðə nɛɹoʊ æliweɪ bɪtwin ə klɔθ mɝtʃəns ʃɑp ən ə pɑɾɝz wɝks əz ðə pɛɹ ʌv wɪmən lɪŋk baɪ ə sɪlvɝi liʃ pæs baɪ, hɛɾɪŋ daʊn ðə kɑbəlstoʊn stʃɹit təwɔɹd fɑlm hɑɹbɝ. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt dɛɹ əlaʊ ðət pɛɹ tə kʌm tu kloʊz. ðə pipəl ɪn ðə stʃɹit meɪd weɪ fəɹ ðoʊz tu ivən mɔɹ kwɪkli ðən ðeɪ dɪd fəɹ sintʃæn soʊlʒɝz, əɹ ði əkeɪʒənəl noʊbəlz pɑlɑnkwɪn, θɪkli kɝteɪnd naʊ ðət ðə deɪz wɝ koʊld. ivən ðə stʃɹiɾ ɑɹɾəsts dɪd nɑɾ ɔfɝ tə dʒɹɔ ðɛm ɪn tʃɔks əɹ pɛnsəlz, ɔlðoʊ ðeɪ pɛstɝɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls. nɪneɪivz maʊθ taɪɾənd əz əɹ aɪz fɑloʊd ðə sʌldəm ən ðə deɪmeɪn θɹu ðə kɹaʊd. ivən æftɝ wiks ɪn ðə taʊn, ðə saɪt sɪkən hɝ. pɝhæps ɪt sɪkən əɹ mɔɹ, naʊ. ʃi kəd nɑɾ ɪmædʒən duɪŋ ðət tə ɛni wʊmən, nɑɾ ivən mɔɪɹeɪn əɹ liɑnʒɹɪn.

Nynaeve pressed Elayne back into the narrow alleyway between a cloth merchant's shop and a potter's works as the pair of women linked by a silvery leash passed by, heading down the cobblestone street toward Falme harbor. They did not dare allow that pair to come too close. The people in the street made way for those two even more quickly than they did for Seanchan soldiers, or the occasional noble's palanquin, thickly curtained now that the days were cold. Even the street artists did not offer to draw them in chalks or pencils, although they pestered everyone else. Nynaeve's mouth tightened as her eyes followed the sul'dam and the damane through the crowd. Even after weeks in the town, the sight sickened her. Perhaps it sickened her more, now. She could not imagine doing that to any woman, not even Moiraine or Liandrin.

wɛl, meɪbi liɑnʒɹɪn, ʃi ədmɪɾəd saʊɝli. səmtaɪmz, ət naɪt, ɪn ðə smɔl, smɛli ɹum ðə tu ʌv əm hæd ɹɛntəɾ əbʌv ə fɪʃmɑŋɡɝ, ʃi θɔɾ ʌv wʌt ʃi wəd laɪk tə də tə liɑnʒɹɪn wən ʃi ɡɑɾ əɹ hænz ɑn hɝ. liɑnʒɹɪn ivən mɔɹ ðən sjuɹɔθ. mɔɹ ðən wʌns ʃi hæd bɪn ʃɑkt əɾ əɹ oʊn kɹulti, ivən waɪl ʃi wɑz dɪlaɪɾəd əɾ əɹ ɪnvɛntɪvnəs.

Well, maybe Liandrin, she admitted sourly. Sometimes, at night, in the small, smelly room the two of them had rented above a fishmonger, she thought of what she would like to do to Liandrin when she got her hands on her. Liandrin even more than Suroth. More than once she had been shocked at her own cruelty, even while she was delighted at her inventiveness.

stɪl tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kip ðə pɛɹ ɪn saɪt, hɝ aɪz fɛl ɑn ə boʊni mæn, wɛl daʊn ðə stʃɹit, bɪfɔɹ ðə ʃɪftɪŋ θɹɔŋ hɪɾ ɪm əɡɛn. ʃi hæɾ oʊnli ə flæʃ ʌv ə bɪɡ noʊz ɪn ə nɛɹoʊ feɪs. hi wɔɹ ə ɹɪtʃ bɹɑnz vɛlvət ɹoʊb ə sintʃæn kʌɾ oʊvɝ ɪz kloʊðz, bʌt ʃi θɔt ðəɾ i wɑz noʊ sintʃæn, ðoʊ ðə sɝvən fɑloʊɪŋ ɪm wɑz, ən ə sɝvən ə haɪ dɪɡɹi, wɪð wʌn tɛmpəl ʃeɪvd. ðə loʊkəl pipəl hæd nɑt teɪkən tə sintʃæn fæʃənz, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ðət wʌn. ðət lʊk laɪk pdən feɪn, ʃi θɔɾ ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli. ɪt kʊdn bi. nɑt hɪɹ.

Still trying to keep the pair in sight, her eyes fell on a bony man, well down the street, before the shifting throng hid him again. She had only a flash of a big nose in a narrow face. He wore a rich bronze velvet robe of Seanchan cut over his clothes, but she thought that he was no Seanchan, though the servant following him was, and a servant of high degree, with one temple shaved. The local people had not taken to Seanchan fashions, particularly that one. That looked like Padan Fain, she thought incredulously. It couldn't be. Not here.

"nɪneɪiv," ɪleɪn sɛd sɔfli, "kʊd wi muv ɑn, naʊ? ðət fɛloʊ sɛlɪŋ æpəlz ɪz lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪz teɪbəl əz ɪf hiz θɪŋkɪŋ i hæd mɔɹ ə fju moʊməns əɡoʊ, ən aɪ wəd nɑt wɑn ɪm wʌndɝɪŋ wʌɾ aɪ hæv ɪn maɪ pɑkəts."

"Nynaeve," Elayne said softly, "could we move on, now? That fellow selling apples is looking at his table as if he's thinking he had more a few moments ago, and I would not want him wondering what I have in my pockets."

ðeɪ boʊθ wɔɹ lɔŋ koʊts meɪɾ ə ʃipskɪn, wɪð ðə flis tɝn ɪn ən bɹaɪt ɹɛd spaɪɹəlz ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd əkɹɔs ðə bɹɛst. ɪt wɑz kʌntʃɹi ɡɑɹb, bʌɾ ɪt pæst wɛl ɪnʌf ɪn fɑlm, wɛɹ mɛni pipəl hæd kʌm ɪn fɹəm ðə fɑɹmz ən vɪlədʒəz. əmʌŋ soʊ mɛni stʃɹeɪnʒɝz ðə tu ʌv əm hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə sɪŋk ɪn ənnoʊɾɪst. nɪneɪiv hæd koʊmd aʊɾ əɹ bɹeɪd, ən əɹ ɡoʊld ɹɪŋ, ðə sɝpən iɾɪŋ ɪts oʊn teɪl, naʊ nɛsəld ʌndɝ əɹ dʒɹɛs bɪsaɪd lænz hɛvi ɹɪŋ ɑn ðə lɛðɝ kɔɹɾ ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk.

They both wore long coats made of sheepskin, with the fleece turned in and bright red spirals embroidered across the breast. It was country garb, but it passed well enough in Falme, where many people had come in from the farms and villages. Among so many strangers the two of them had been able to sink in unnoticed. Nynaeve had combed out her braid, and her gold ring, the serpent eating its own tail, now nestled under her dress beside Lan's heavy ring on the leather cord around her neck.

ðə lɑɹdʒ pɑkəts ʌv ɪleɪnz koʊt bʌlʒd səspɪʃəsli.

The large pockets of Elayne's coat bulged suspiciously.

"ju stoʊl ðoʊz æpəlz?" nɪneɪiv hɪs kwaɪətli, pʊlɪŋ ɪleɪn aʊɾ ɪndə ðə kɹaʊɾəd stʃɹit. "ɪleɪn, wi doʊn əv tə stil. nɑt jɛt, ɛniweɪ."

"You stole those apples?" Nynaeve hissed quietly, pulling Elayne out into the crowded street. "Elayne, we don't have to steal. Not yet, anyway."

"noʊ? haʊ mʌtʃ mʌni də wɪv lɛft? juv bɪn 'nɑt hʌŋɡɹi' vɛɹi ɔfən ət miltaɪmz ðə læs fju deɪz."

"No? How much money do we have left? You have been 'not hungry' very often at mealtimes the last few days."

"wɛl, aɪm nɑt hʌŋɡɹi," nɪneɪiv snæpt, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɪɡnɔɹ ðə hɑloʊ ɪn əɹ mɪɾəl. ɛvɹiθɪŋ kɑs kənsɪɾɝəbli mɔɹ ðən ʃi hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd; ʃi hæd hɝd loʊkəl pipəl kəmpleɪnɪŋ əbaʊt haʊ pɹaɪsəz hæd ɹɪzən sɪns ðə sintʃæn keɪm. "ɡɪv mi wʌn ə ðoʊz." ði æpəl ɪleɪn dʌɡ aʊɾ ə hɝ pɑkət wɑz smɔl ən hɑɹd, bʌɾ ɪt kɹʌntʃt wɪð ə dɪlɪʃəs switnəs wən nɪneɪiv bɪɾ ɪndə ɪt. ʃi lɪk ðə dʒus fɹəm əɹ lɪps. "haʊ dɪd jə mænədʒ tə - " ʃi dʒɝkt ɪleɪn tə ə hɔlt ən pɪɹɾ ɪndə hɝ feɪs. "dɪd jə . . . ? dɪd jə . . . ?" ʃi kəd nɑt θɪŋk ʌv ə weɪ tə seɪ ɪt wɪð soʊ mɛni stʃɹimɪŋ baɪ, bʌɾ ɪleɪn ʌndɝstʊd.

"Well, I am not hungry," Nynaeve snapped, trying to ignore the hollow in her middle. Everything cost considerably more than she had expected; she had heard local people complaining about how prices had risen since the Seanchan came. "Give me one of those." The apple Elayne dug out of her pocket was small and hard, but it crunched with a delicious sweetness when Nynaeve bit into it. She licked the juice from her lips. "How did you manage to - " She jerked Elayne to a halt and peered into her face. "Did you . . . ? Did you . . . ?" She could not think of a way to say it with so many streaming by, but Elayne understood.

"oʊnli ə lɪɾəl. aɪ meɪd ðət stæk ʌv oʊl mɛlənz wɪð ðə sɑf spɑts fɔl, ən wən i stɑɹɾəd pʊɾɪŋ əm bæk. . . ." ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ivən əv ðə ɡɹeɪs, əz nɪneɪiv sɔ ɪt, tə blʌʃ əɹ lʊk ɪmbɛɹəst. ʌnkənsɝnədli iɾɪŋ wʌn ə ði æpəlz, ʃi ʃɹʌɡd. "ðɛɹ ɪz noʊ nid tə fɹaʊn ət mi laɪk ðæt. aɪ lʊkt kɛɹfəli tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðəɹ wɑz noʊ deɪmeɪn kloʊs." ʃi snɪft. "ɪf aɪ wɝ biɪŋ hɛl pɹɪznɝ, aɪ wəd nɑt hɛlp maɪ kæptɝz faɪn ʌðɝ wɪmən tə ɛnslɑv. ɔlðoʊ, ðə weɪ ðiz fɑlmɛn bɪheɪv, jə wəd θɪŋk ðeɪ wɝ laɪflɔŋ sɝvəns ə ðoʊz u ʃəd bi ðɛɹ ɛnəmiz tə ðə dɛθ." ʃi lʊkt ɝaʊnd, oʊpənli kəntɛmptʃuəs, ət ðə pipəl hɝiɪŋ baɪ; ɪt wɑz pɑsəbəl tə fɑloʊ ðə pæθ ʌv ɛni sintʃæn, ivən kɑmən soʊlʒɝz ən ivən əɾ ə dɪstəns, baɪ ðə ɹɪpəlz ə boʊɪŋ. "ðeɪ ʃəd ɹɪzɪst. ðeɪ ʃəd faɪt bæk."

"Only a little. I made that stack of old melons with the soft spots fall, and when he started putting them back. . . ." She did not even have the grace, as Nynaeve saw it, to blush or look embarrassed. Unconcernedly eating one of the apples, she shrugged. "There is no need to frown at me like that. I looked carefully to make sure there was no damane close." She sniffed. "If I were being held prisoner, I would not help my captors find other women to enslave. Although, the way these Falmen behave, you would think they were lifelong servants of those who should be their enemies to the death." She looked around, openly contemptuous, at the people hurrying by; it was possible to follow the path of any Seanchan, even common soldiers and even at a distance, by the ripples of bowing. "They should resist. They should fight back."

"haʊ? əɡɛnst . . . ðæt."

"How? Against . . . that."

ðeɪ hæd tə stɛp tə ðə saɪɾ ə ðə stʃɹiɾ əlɔŋ wɪð ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls əz ə sintʃæn pətʃɹoʊl nɪɹd, klaɪmɪŋ fɹəm ðə dɝɛkʃən ə ðə hɑɹbɝ. nɪneɪiv mænədʒ ðə baʊ, hænz ɑn niz, wɪð feɪs skul tə ə pɝfək smuðnəs; ɪleɪn wɑz sloʊɝ, ən meɪɾ əɹ baʊ wɪð ə dɪsteɪsfəl twɪst ə hɝ maʊθ.

They had to step to the side of the street along with everyone else as a Seanchan patrol neared, climbing from the direction of the harbor. Nynaeve managed the bow, hands on knees, with face schooled to a perfect smoothness; Elayne was slower, and made her bow with a distasteful twist of her mouth.

ðəɹ wɝ twɛnti ɑɹmɝd mɛn ən wɪmən ɪn ðə pətʃɹoʊl, ɹaɪɾɪŋ hɔɹsəz, fəɹ wɪtʃ nɪneɪiv wɑz ɡɹeɪtfəl. ʃi kəd nɑt bɪkʌm juz tə siɪŋ pipəl ɹaɪɾɪŋ θɪŋz ðət lʊk laɪk bɹɑnz-skeɪld, teɪləs kæts, ən ə ɹaɪɾɝ ɑn wʌn ə ðə flaɪɪŋ bists wɑz ɔlweɪz ɪnʌf tə meɪk əɹ fil dɪzi; ʃi wɑz ɡlæd ðəɹ wɝ soʊ fju ʌv ðɛm. stɪl, tu liʃt kɹitʃɝz tʃɹɑɾəd əlɔŋ wɪð ðə pətʃɹoʊl, laɪk wɪŋɡləs bɝdz wɪð kɔɹs lɛðɝ skɪn, ən ʃɑɹp biks haɪɝ əbʌv ðə kɑbəlstoʊnz ðən ðə hɛlməɾɪd hɛdz ə ðə soʊlʒɝ. ðɛɹ lɔŋ, sɪnjui lɛɡz lʊkt əz ɪf ðeɪ kəd ɹʌn fæstɝ ðən ɛni hɔɹs.

There were twenty armored men and women in the patrol, riding horses, for which Nynaeve was grateful. She could not become used to seeing people riding things that looked like bronze-scaled, tailless cats, and a rider on one of the flying beasts was always enough to make her feel dizzy; she was glad there were so few of them. Still, two leashed creatures trotted along with the patrol, like wingless birds with coarse leather skin, and sharp beaks higher above the cobblestones than the helmeted heads of the soldier. Their long, sinewy legs looked as if they could run faster than any horse.

ʃi stʃɹeɪɾənd sloʊli æftɝ ðə sintʃæn wɝ ɡɔn. səm ə ðoʊz u hæd baʊd fəɹ ðə pətʃɹoʊl keɪm kloʊs tə ɹʌnɪŋ; noʊ wʌn wɑz kʌmftəɹbəl ət ðə saɪɾ ə ðə sintʃænz bists ɪksɛp ðə sintʃæn ðɛmsɛlvz. "ɪleɪn," ʃi sɛd sɔfli əz ðeɪ ɹɪzum ðɛɹ klaɪm, "ɪf wəɹ kɑt, aɪ swɛɹ ðət bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ kɪl ʌs, əɹ də wʌtɛvɝ ðeɪ du, əl bɛɡ ðɛm ɑn bɛndɪd niz tə lemi stʃɹaɪp jə fɹəm tɑp tə bɑɾəm wɪð ðə staʊɾəst swɪtʃ aɪ kən faɪnd! ɪf jə stɪl kæn lɝn tə bi kɛɹfəl, meɪbi ɪts taɪm tə θɪŋk əbaʊt sɛndɪŋ jə bæk tə tɑɹ vəlɑn, əɹ hoʊm tə keɪɛmlɪn, əɹ ɛniwɛɹ bʌt hɪɹ."

She straightened slowly after the Seanchan were gone. Some of those who had bowed for the patrol came close to running; no one was comfortable at the sight of the Seanchan's beasts except the Seanchan themselves. "Elayne," she said softly as they resumed their climb, "if we are caught, I swear that before they kill us, or do whatever they do, I will beg them on bended knees to let me stripe you from top to bottom with the stoutest switch I can find! If you still can't learn to be careful, maybe it's time to think about sending you back to Tar Valon, or home to Caemlyn, or anywhere but here."

"aɪ æm kɛɹfəl. ət list aɪ lʊk tə bi ʃʊɹ ðəɹ wɑz noʊ deɪmeɪn kloʊs baɪ. wʌɾ əbaʊt ju? aɪ hæv sin jə tʃænəl wɪð wʌn ɪn pleɪn saɪt."

"I am careful. At least I looked to be sure there was no damane close by. What about you? I have seen you channel with one in plain sight."

"aɪ meɪd ʃʊɹ ðeɪ wɝn lʊkɪŋ ət mi," nɪneɪiv mʌɾɝd. ʃi hæd hæd tə bɔl ʌp ɔl əɹ æŋɡɝ ət wɪmən biɪŋ tʃeɪn laɪk ænəməlz tə mænədʒ ɪt. "æn aɪ oʊnli dɪɾ ɪt wʌns. ən ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə tʃɹɪkəl."

"I made sure they weren't looking at me," Nynaeve muttered. She had had to ball up all her anger at women being chained like animals to manage it. "And I only did it once. And it was only a trickle."

"ə tʃɹɪkəl? wi hæd tə spɛn θɹi deɪz haɪɾɪŋ ɪn əɹ ɹum bɹiðɪŋ fɪʃ waɪl ðeɪ sɝtʃt ðə taʊn fəɹ huɛvɝ hæd dʌn ɪt. dʒju kɔl ðət biɪŋ kɛɹfəl?"

"A trickle? We had to spend three days hiding in our room breathing fish while they searched the town for whoever had done it. Do you call that being careful?"

"aɪ hæd tə noʊ ɪf ðəɹ wɑz ə weɪ tə ənfæstən ðoʊz kɑlɝz." ʃi θɔt ðəɹ wɑz. ʃi wəɾ əv tə tɛst wʌn mɔɹ kɑlɝ ət lis bɪfɔɹ ʃi wɑz sɝɾən, ən ʃi wɑz nɑt lʊkɪŋ fɔɹwɝd tə ɪt. ʃi hæd θɔt, laɪk ɪleɪn, ðət ðə deɪmeɪn mʌst ɔl bi pɹɪznɝz iɡɝ tə ɪskeɪp, bʌɾ ɪt hæd bɪn ðə wʊmən ɪn ðə kɑlɝ u ɹeɪz ðə pɹaɪ.
