"I had to know if there was a way to unfasten those collars." She thought there was. She would have to test one more collar at least before she was certain, and she was not looking forward to it. She had thought, like Elayne, that the damane must all be prisoners eager to escape, but it had been the woman in the collar who raised the pry.

ə mæn pʊʃɪŋ ə bæɹoʊ ðət bʌmpt oʊvɝ ðə kɑbəlstoʊnz pæs baɪ ðɛm, kɹaɪɪŋ ɪz sɝvəsəz tə ʃɑɹpən sɪzɝz ən naɪvz. "ðeɪ ʃəd ɹɪzɪst, sʌmhaʊ," ɪleɪn ɡɹaʊld. "ðeɪ ækt əz ɪf ðeɪ də nɑt si ɛniθɪŋ ðət hæpənz ɝaʊn əm ɪf ðɛɹz ə sintʃæn ɪn ɪt."

A man pushing a barrow that bumped over the cobblestones passed by them, crying his services to sharpen scissors and knives. "They should resist, somehow," Elayne growled. "They act as if they do not see anything that happens around them if there's a Seanchan in it."

nɪneɪiv oʊnli saɪd. ɪt dɪd nɑt hɛlp ðət ʃi θɔɾ ɪleɪn wɑz ət lis pɑɹtli ɹaɪt. ət fɝst ʃi hæd θɔt səm ə ðə fɑlmɛn səbmɪʃən, ət list, mʌs bi ə poʊz, bʌt ʃi hæd faʊnd noʊ ɛvəɾəns ʌv ɛni ɹɪzɪstəns əɾ ɔl. ʃi hæd lʊkt ət fɝst, hoʊpɪŋ tə faɪn hɛlp ɪn fɹiɪŋ ɛɡwin ən mɪn, bʌɾ ɛvɹiwʌn tʊk fɹaɪɾ ət ðə mɛɹəs hɪn ðət ðeɪ maɪɾ əpoʊz ðə sintʃæn, ən ʃi stɑpt æskɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ʃi dʒɹu ðə ɹɔŋ sɔɹɾ ʌv ətɛnʃən. ɪn tʃɹuθ, ʃi kəd nɑɾ ɪmædʒən haʊ ðə pipəl kəd faɪt. mɑnstɝz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. haʊ kən jə faɪt mɑnstɝz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ?

Nynaeve only sighed. It did not help that she thought Elayne was at least partly right. At first she had thought some of the Falmen submission, at least, must be a pose, but she had found no evidence of any resistance at all. She had looked at first, hoping to find help in freeing Egwene and Min, but everyone took fright at the merest hint that they might oppose the Seanchan, and she stopped asking before she drew the wrong sort of attention. In truth, she could not imagine how the people could fight. Monsters and Aes Sedai. How can you fight monsters and Aes Sedai?

əhɛd stʊd faɪv tɔl stoʊn haʊsəz, əmʌŋ ðə lɑɹdʒəst ɪn ðə taʊn, ɔl təɡɛðɝ meɪkɪŋ ʌp ə blɑk. wʌn stʃɹit ʃɔɹɾ ə ðɛm, nɪneɪiv faʊn ən æliweɪ bɪsaɪɾ ə teɪlɝ ʃɑp, wɛɹ ðeɪ kəd kip ən aɪ ɑn səm ə ðə tɔl haʊsəz' ɛntʃɹənsəz, ət list. ɪt wɑz nɑt pɑsəbəl tə si ɛvɹi dɔɹ ət wʌns - ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə ɹɪsk lɛɾɪŋ ɪleɪn ɡoʊ ɔf ɑn əɹ oʊn tə wɑtʃ mɔɹ - bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɑt waɪz tə ɡoʊ ɛni kloʊsɝ. əbʌv ðə ɹuftɑps, ɑn ðə nɛkst stʃɹit, ðə ɡoʊldən hɔk bænɝ ə ðə haɪ lɔɹd tʃɹɑk flæpt ɪn ðə wɪnd.

Ahead stood five tall stone houses, among the largest in the town, all together making up a block. One street short of them, Nynaeve found an alleyway beside a tailor shop, where they could keep an eye on some of the tall houses' entrances, at least. It was not possible to see every door at once - she did not want to risk letting Elayne go off on her own to watch more - but it was not wise to go any closer. Above the rooftops, on the next street, the golden hawk banner of the High Lord Turak flapped in the wind.

oʊnli wɪmən wɛn ɪn əɹ aʊɾ ə ðoʊz haʊsəz, ən moʊst ə ðoʊz wɝ sʌldəm, əloʊn əɹ wɪð deɪmeɪn ɪn toʊ. ðə bɪldɪŋz hæd bɪn teɪkən oʊvɝ baɪ ðə sintʃæn tə haʊs ðə deɪmeɪn. ɛɡwin hæd tə bi ɪn ðɛɹ, ən laɪkli mɪn; ðeɪ hæd faʊnd noʊ saɪn ə mɪn soʊ fɑɹ, ðoʊ ɪt wɑz pɑsəbəl ʃi wɑz əz hɪɾən baɪ ðə kɹaʊdz əz ðeɪ. nɪneɪiv hæd hɝd mɛni teɪlz ʌv wɪmən ən ɡɝlz biɪŋ sizd ɑn ðə stʃɹits əɹ bɹɔɾ ɪn fɹəm ðə vɪlədʒəz; ðeɪ ɔl wɛn ɪndə ðoʊz haʊsəz, ən ɪf ðeɪ wɝ sin əɡɛn, ðeɪ wɔɹ ə kɑlɝ.

Only women went in or out of those houses, and most of those were sul'dam, alone or with damane in tow. The buildings had been taken over by the Seanchan to house the damane. Egwene had to be in there, and likely Min; they had found no sign of Min so far, though it was possible she was as hidden by the crowds as they. Nynaeve had heard many tales of women and girls being seized on the streets or brought in from the villages; they all went into those houses, and if they were seen again, they wore a collar.

sɛɾəlɪŋ hɝsɛlf ɑn ə kɹeɪt bɪsaɪɾ ɪleɪn, ʃi dʌɡ ɪndə ði ʌðɝ wʊmənz koʊt fəɹ ə hændfʊl ə ðə smɔl æpəlz. ðəɹ wɝ fjuɝ loʊkəl foʊk ɪn ðə stʃɹits hɪɹ. ɛvɹiwʌn nu wʌt ðə haʊsəz wɝ, ən ɛvɹiwʌn əvɔɪɾəd ðɛm, dʒʌst əz ðeɪ əvɔɪɾəd ðə steɪbəlz wɛɹ ðə sintʃæn kɛp ðɛɹ bists. ɪt wɑz nɑt dɪfəkəl tə kip ən aɪ ɑn ðə dɔɹz θɹu speɪsəz bɪtwin ðə pæsɝzbi. dʒʌs tu wɪmən stɑpɪŋ fəɹ ə baɪt; dʒʌs tu mɔɹ pipəl u kəd nɑɾ əfɔɹd tə iɾ əɾ ən ɪn. nʌθɪŋ tə ətʃɹæk mɔɹ ðən ə pæsɪŋ ɡlæns.

Settling herself on a crate beside Elayne, she dug into the other woman's coat for a handful of the small apples. There were fewer local folk in the streets here. Everyone knew what the houses were, and everyone avoided them, just as they avoided the stables where the Seanchan kept their beasts. It was not difficult to keep an eye on the doors through spaces between the passersby. Just two women stopping for a bite; just two more people who could not afford to eat at an inn. Nothing to attract more than a passing glance.

iɾɪŋ məkænɪkli, nɪneɪiv tʃɹaɪd wʌns mɔɹ tə plæn. biɪŋ eɪbəl tə oʊpən ðə kɑlɝ - ɪf ʃi ɹɪli kəd - dɪd noʊ ɡʊɾ əɾ ɔl ənlɛs ʃi kəd ɹitʃ ɛɡwin. ði æpəlz dɪd nɑt teɪst soʊ swiɾ ɛnimɔɹ.

Eating mechanically, Nynaeve tried once more to plan. Being able to open the collar - if she really could - did no good at all unless she could reach Egwene. The apples did not taste so sweet anymore.

fɹəm ðə nɛɹoʊ wɪndoʊ ʌv əɹ taɪni ɹum ʌndɝ ði ivz, wʌn ʌv ə nʌmbɝ ɹʌfli wɔl təɡɛðɝ fɹəm wʌtɛvɝ hæd bɪn ðəɹ bɪfɔɹ, ɛɡwin kəd si ðə ɡɑɹɾən wɛɹ deɪmeɪn wɝ biɪŋ wɔk baɪ ðɛɹ sʌldəm. ɪt hæd bɪn sɛvɹəl ɡɑɹɾənz bɪfɔɹ ðə sintʃæn nɑk daʊn ðə wɔlz ðət sɛpɝeɪɾəd əm ən tʊk ðə bɪɡ haʊsəz tə kip ðɛɹ deɪmeɪn. ðə tʃɹiz wɝ ɔl bʌt lifləs, bʌt ðə deɪmeɪn wɝ stɪl teɪkən aʊt fəɹ ɛɹ, wɛðɝ ðeɪ wɑntəɾ ɪɾ əɹ nɑt. ɛɡwin wɑtʃt ðə ɡɑɹɾən kəz ɹɛnə wɑz daʊn ðɛɹ, tɔkɪŋ wɪð ənʌðɝ sʌldəm, ən əz lɔŋ əz ʃi kəd si ɹɛnə, ðən ɹɛnə wɑz nɑt gɑnə ɛntɝ ən sɝpɹaɪz hɝ.

From the narrow window of her tiny room under the eaves, one of a number roughly walled together from whatever had been there before, Egwene could see the garden where damane were being walked by their sul'dam. It had been several gardens before the Seanchan knocked down the walls that separated them and took the big houses to keep their damane. The trees were all but leafless, but the damane were still taken out for air, whether they wanted it or not. Egwene watched the garden because Renna was down there, talking with another sul'dam, and as long as she could see Renna, then Renna was not going to enter and surprise her.

səm ʌðɝ sʌldəm maɪt kʌm - ðəɹ wɝ mɛni mɔɹ sʌldəm ðən deɪmeɪn, ən ɛvɹi sʌldəm wɑntəɾ əɹ tɝn wɛɹɪŋ ə bɹeɪslət; ðeɪ kɔld ɪt biɪŋ kəmplit - bʌt ɹɛnə stɪl hæd tʃɑɹdʒ ə hɝ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ, ən ɪt wɑz ɹɛnə hu wɔɹ əɹ bɹeɪslət fɔɹ taɪmz aʊɾ ə faɪv. ɪf ɛniwʌn keɪm, ðeɪ wəd faɪnd noʊ ɪmpɛɾəmənt tə ɛntɝɪŋ. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ lɑks ɑn ðə dɔɹz ə deɪmeɪnz ɹumz. ɛɡwinz ɹum hɛld oʊnli ə hɑɹd, nɛɹoʊ bɛd, ə wɑʃstænd wɪð ə tʃɪpt pɪtʃɝ ən boʊl, wʌn tʃɛɹ ən ə smɔl teɪbəl, bʌɾ ɪt hæd noʊ ɹum fəɹ mɔɹ. deɪmeɪn hæd noʊ niɾ ə kʌmfɝt, əɹ pɹaɪvəsi, əɹ pəzɛʃənz. deɪmeɪn wɝ pəzɛʃənz. mɪn hæɾ ə ɹum dʒʌs laɪk ðɪs, ɪn ənʌðɝ haʊs, bʌt mɪn kəd kʌm ən ɡoʊ əz ʃi wʊd, əɹ ɔlmoʊst əz ʃi wʊd. sintʃæn wɝ ɡɹeɪt wʌnz fəɹ ɹulz; ðeɪ hæd mɔɹ, fəɹ ɛvɹiwʌn, ðən ðə waɪt taʊɝ dɪd fəɹ nɑvəsɪz.

Some other sul'dam might come - there were many more sul'dam than damane, and every sul'dam wanted her turn wearing a bracelet; they called it being complete - but Renna still had charge of her training, and it was Renna who wore her bracelet four times out of five. If anyone came, they would find no impediment to entering. There were no locks on the doors of damane's rooms. Egwene's room held only a hard, narrow bed, a washstand with a chipped pitcher and bowl, one chair and a small table, but it had no room for more. Damane had no need of comfort, or privacy, or possessions. Damane were possessions. Min had a room just like this, in another house, but Min could come and go as she would, or almost as she would. Seanchan were great ones for rules; they had more, for everyone, than the White Tower did for novices.

ɛɡwin stʊd fɑɹ bæk fɹəm ðə wɪndoʊ. ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑn ɛni ʌv ðə wɪmən bɪloʊ tə lʊk ʌp ən si ðə ɡloʊ ðət ʃi nu sɝaʊndəɾ əɹ əz ʃi tʃænəl ðə wʌn paʊɝ, pɹoʊbɪŋ dɛləkətli ət ðə kɑlɝ ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk, sɝtʃɪŋ fjuɾɪlli; ʃi kəd nɑɾ ivən tɛl wɛðɝ ðə bænd wɑz woʊvən əɹ meɪɾ ə lɪŋks - səmtaɪmz ɪt simd wʌn, səmtaɪmz ði ʌðɝ - bʌɾ ɪt simd ɔl ʌv ə pis ɔl ðə taɪm. ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə taɪni tʃɹɪkəl ə ðə paʊɝ, ðə mɛɹəs dʒɹɪp ðət ʃi kəɾ ɪmædʒən, bʌɾ ɪt stɪl biɾɪd swɛɾ ɑn əɹ feɪs ən meɪɾ əɹ stʌmək klɛntʃ. ðət wɑz wʌn ə ðə pɹɑpɝɾiz ə ði æɾəm; ɪf ə deɪmeɪn tʃɹaɪd tə tʃænəl wɪθaʊɾ ə sʌldəm wɛɹɪŋ əɹ bɹeɪslət, ʃi fɛl sɪk, ən ðə mɔɹ ə ðə paʊɝ ʃi tʃænəld, ðə sɪkɝ ʃi bɪkeɪm. laɪɾɪŋ ə kændəl bɪɑn ðə ɹitʃ ə hɝ ɑɹm wʊɾə meɪɾ ɛɡwin vɑmət. wʌns ɹɛnə hæɾ ɔɹɾɝd əɹ tə dʒʌɡəl əɹ taɪni bɔlz ə laɪt wɪð ðə bɹeɪslət laɪɪŋ ɑn ðə teɪbəl. ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ stɪl meɪɾ əɹ ʃʌɾɝ.

Egwene stood far back from the window. She did not want any of the women below to look up and see the glow that she knew surrounded her as she channeled the One Power, probing delicately at the collar around her neck, searching futilely; she could not even tell whether the band was woven or made of links - sometimes it seemed one, sometimes the other - but it seemed all of a piece all the time. It was only a tiny trickle of the Power, the merest drip that she could imagine, but it still beaded sweat on her face and made her stomach clench. That was one of the properties of the a'dam; if a damane tried to channel without a sul'dam wearing her bracelet, she felt sick, and the more of the Power she channeled, the sicker she became. Lighting a candle beyond the reach of her arm would have made Egwene vomit. Once Renna had ordered her to juggle her tiny balls of light with the bracelet lying on the table. Remembering still made her shudder.

naʊ, ðə sɪlvɝ liʃ sneɪkt əkɹɔs ðə bɛɹ flɔɹ ən ʌp ði ənpeɪntɪd wʊɾən wɔl tə wɛɹ ðə bɹeɪslət hʌŋ ɑn ə pɛɡ. ðə saɪɾ ʌv ɪt hæŋɪŋ ðəɹ meɪɾ əɹ dʒɔz klɛntʃ wɪð fjʊɹi. ə dɔɡ liʃt soʊ kɛɹləsli cʊɾə ɹʌn əweɪ. ɪf ə deɪmeɪn muvd əɹ bɹeɪsləɾ əz mʌtʃ əz ə fʊt fɹəm wɛɹ ɪt hæd læs bɪn tʌtʃt baɪ ə sʌldəm. . . . ɹɛnə hæd meɪɾ əɹ də ðæt, tu - hæd meɪɾ əɹ kæɹi hɝ oʊn bɹeɪsləɾ əkɹɔs ðə ɹum. əɹ tʃɹaɪ tə. ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪt hæɾ oʊnli bɪn mɪnəts bɪfɔɹ ðə sʌldəm snæp ðə bɹeɪslət fɝmli ɑn əɹ oʊn ɹɪst, bʌt tə ɛɡwin ðə skɹimɪŋ ən ðə kɹæmps ðət hæd hæɾ əɹ ɹaɪðɪŋ ɑn ðə flɔɹ hæd sim tə ɡoʊ ɑn fəɹ aʊɝz.

Now, the silver leash snaked across the bare floor and up the unpainted wooden wall to where the bracelet hung on a peg. The sight of it hanging there made her jaws clench with fury. A dog leashed so carelessly could have run away. If a damane moved her bracelet as much as a foot from where it had last been touched by a sul'dam. . . . Renna had made her do that, too - had made her carry her own bracelet across the room. Or try to. She was sure it had only been minutes before the sul'dam snapped the bracelet firmly on her own wrist, but to Egwene the screaming and the cramps that had had her writhing on the floor had seemed to go on for hours.

sʌmwʌn tæpt ət ðə dɔɹ, ən ɛɡwin dʒʌmpt, bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɹilaɪzd ɪt kəd nɑt bi ə sʌldəm. nʌn ə ðɛm wəd nɑk fɝst. ʃi lɛt seɪaɪdɑɹ ɡoʊ, ɛniweɪ; ʃi wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə fil dɪsaɪɾədli ɪl. "mɪn?"

Someone tapped at the door, and Egwene jumped, before she realized it could not be a sul'dam. None of them would knock first. She let saidar go, anyway; she was beginning to feel decidedly ill. "Min?"

"hɪɹ aɪm fəɹ maɪ wikli vɪzət," mɪn ənaʊnst əz ʃi slɪpt ɪnsaɪɾ ən ʃʌt ðə dɔɹ. hɝ tʃɪɹaɪnəs saʊndəɾ ə lɪɾəl fɔɹst, bʌt ʃi ɔlweɪz dɪd wʌt ʃi kəd tə kip ɛɡwinz spɪɹəts ʌp. "haʊ dʒju laɪk ɪt?" ʃi spʌn ɪn ə lɪɾəl sɝkəl, ʃoʊɪŋ ɔf əɹ dɑɹk ɡɹin wʊl dʒɹɛs ə sintʃæn kʌt. ə hɛvi, mætʃɪŋ kloʊk hʌŋ oʊvɝ əɹ ɑɹm. ðəɹ wɑz ivən ə ɡɹin ɹɪbən kætʃɪŋ ʌp əɹ dɑɹk hɛɹ, ðoʊ hɝ hɛɹ wɑz hɑɹdli lɔŋ ɪnʌf fəɹ ɪt. hɝ naɪf wɑz stɪl ɪn ɪts ʃiθ əɾ əɹ weɪst, ðoʊ. ɛɡwin hæd bɪn sɝpɹaɪzd wən mɪn fɝst ʃoʊɾ ʌp wɛɹɪŋ ɪt, bʌɾ ɪt sim ðə sintʃæn tʃɹʌstɪɾ ɛvɹiwʌn. əntɪl ðeɪ bɹoʊk ə ɹul.

"Here I am for my weekly visit," Min announced as she slipped inside and shut the door. Her cheeriness sounded a little forced, but she always did what she could to keep Egwene's spirits up. "How do you like it?" She spun in a little circle, showing off her dark green wool dress of Seanchan cut. A heavy, matching cloak hung over her arm. There was even a green ribbon catching up her dark hair, though her hair was hardly long enough for it. Her knife was still in its sheath at her waist, though. Egwene had been surprised when Min first showed up wearing it, but it seemed the Seanchan trusted everyone. Until they broke a rule.

"ɪts pɹɪɾi," ɛɡwin sɛd kɔʃəsli. "bʌt, waɪ?"

"It's pretty," Egwene said cautiously. "But, why?"

"aɪ hævənt ɡɔn oʊvɝ tə ði ɛnəmi, ɪf ðəɾ ɪz wʌt jə ɑɹ θɪŋkɪŋ. ɪt wɑz ðɪs, əɹ ɛls faɪn sʌmpleɪs tə steɪ aʊɾ ɪn ðə taʊn, ən meɪbi nɑt bi eɪbəl tə vɪzət jə əɡɛn." ʃi stɑɹɾəd tə stʃɹæɾəl ðə tʃɛɹ əz ʃi wəɾ əv ɪn bɹitʃɪz, ɡeɪv ə ɹaɪ ʃeɪk ə hɝ hɛd, ən tɝn ɪɾ ɝaʊn tə sɪt. " 'ɛvɹiwʌn əz ə pleɪs ɪn ðə pæɾɝn,' " ʃi mɪmɪkt, " 'æn ðə pleɪs ʌv ɛvɹiwʌn mʌs bi ɹɛɾəli əpɛɹənt.' ðəɾ oʊl hæɡ muleɪən əpɛɹənli ɡɑt taɪɝɾ ə nɑt noʊɪŋ wʌt maɪ pleɪs wɑz ɑn saɪɾ ən dɪsaɪɾɪd aɪ ɹæŋkt wɪð ðə sɝvɪŋ ɡɝlz. ʃi ɡeɪv mi ðə tʃɔɪs. jə ʃəd si səm ə ðə θɪŋz sintʃæn sɝvɪŋ ɡɝlz wɛɹ, ðə wʌnz u sɝv ðə lɔɹdz. ɪt maɪt bi fʌn, bʌt nɑɾ ənlɛs aɪ wɑz bɪtʃɹɑθd, ɔɹ, bɛɾɝ jɛt, mɛɹid. wɛl, ðɛɹz noʊ ɡoʊɪŋ bæk. nɑt jɛt, ɛniweɪ. muleɪən bɝn maɪ koʊɾ ən bɹitʃɪz." ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ tə ʃoʊ wʌt ʃi θɔɾ ə ðæt, ʃi pɪkt ʌp ə ɹɑk fɹəm ə smɔl paɪl ɑn ðə teɪbəl ən baʊnst ɪt fɹəm hæn tə hænd. "ɪɾ ɪzən soʊ bæd," ʃi sɛd wɪð ə læf, "ɪksɛp ðəɾ ɪts bɪn soʊ lɔŋ sɪns aɪ wɔɹ skɝts ðəɾ aɪ kip tʃɹɪpɪŋ oʊvɝ ðɛm."

"I haven't gone over to the enemy, if that is what you are thinking. It was this, or else find someplace to stay out in the town, and maybe not be able to visit you again." She started to straddle the chair as she would have in breeches, gave a wry shake of her head, and turned it around to sit. " 'Everyone has a place in the Pattern,' " she mimicked, " 'and the place of everyone must be readily apparent.' That old hag Mulaen apparently got tired of not knowing what my place was on sight and decided I ranked with the serving girls. She gave me the choice. You should see some of the things Seanchan serving girls wear, the ones who serve the lords. It might be fun, but not unless I was betrothed, or, better yet, married. Well, there's no going back. Not yet, anyway. Mulaen burned my coat and breeches." Grimacing to show what she thought of that, she picked up a rock from a small pile on the table and bounced it from hand to hand. "It isn't so bad," she said with a laugh, "except that it has been so long since I wore skirts that I keep tripping over them."

ɛɡwin hæd hæd tə wɑtʃ əɹ kloʊðz biɪŋ bɝnd, tu, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ðət lʌvli ɡɹin sɪlk. ɪt hæd meɪɾ əɹ ɡlæd ʃi hæd nɑt bɹɔt mɔɹ ə ðə kloʊðz ðə leɪɾi əmælisə hæd ɡɪvən hɝ, ðoʊ ʃi maɪt nɛvɝ si ɛni ʌv ðɛm, əɹ ðə waɪt taʊɝ, əɡɛn. wʌt ʃi hæɾ ɑn naʊ wɑz ðə seɪm dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ ɔl deɪmeɪn wɔɹ. deɪmeɪn əv noʊ pəzɛʃənz, ɪt hæd bɪn ɪkspleɪn tə hɝ. ðə dʒɹɛs ə deɪmeɪn wɛɹz, ðə fud ʃi its, ðə bɛd ʃi slips ɪn, ɑɹ ɔl ɡɪfs fɹəm əɹ sʌldəm. ɪf ə sʌldəm tʃuzəz ðəɾ ə deɪmeɪn slip ɑn ðə flɔɹ ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ɪn ə bɛd, əɹ ɪn ə stɔl ɪn ə steɪbəl, ɪts pjʊɹli ðə tʃɔɪs ə ðə sʌldəm. muleɪən, hu hæd tʃɑɹdʒ ə ðə deɪmeɪn kɔɹɾɝz, hæɾ ə dʒɹoʊnɪŋ neɪzəl vɔɪs, bʌt ʃi wɑz ʃɑɹp wɪð ɛni deɪmeɪn u dɪd nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɛvɹi wɝɾ ə hɝ bɔɹɪŋ lɛktʃɝz.

Egwene had had to watch her clothes being burned, too, including that lovely green silk. It had made her glad she had not brought more of the clothes the Lady Amalisa had given her, though she might never see any of them, or the White Tower, again. What she had on now was the same dark gray all damane wore. Damane have no possessions, it had been explained to her. The dress a damane wears, the food she eats, the bed she sleeps in, are all gifts from her sul'dam. If a sul'dam chooses that a damane sleep on the floor instead of in a bed, or in a stall in a stable, it is purely the choice of the sul'dam. Mulaen, who had charge of the damane quarters, had a droning nasal voice, but she was sharp with any damane who did not remember every word of her boring lectures.

"aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðəɹ wɪl bi ɛni ɡoʊɪŋ bæk fəɹ mi ɛvɝ," ɛɡwin sɛd, saɪɪŋ, sɪŋkɪŋ daʊn ɑn əɹ bɛd. ʃi dʒɛstʃɝd tə ðə ɹɑks ɑn ðə teɪbəl. "ɹɛnə ɡeɪv mi ə tɛst, jɛstɝdeɪ. aɪ pɪkt aʊt ðə pis ʌv aɪɝn ɔɹ, ən ðə kɑpɝ ɔɹ, blaɪndfoʊldɪd, ɛvɹi taɪm ʃi mɪkst əm ʌp. ʃi lɛft əm ɔl hɪɹ tə ɹimaɪn mi ʌv maɪ səksɛs. ʃi sim tə θɪŋk ɪt wɑz səm kaɪndə ɹɪwɔɹd tə bi ɹimaɪndəd."

"I don't think there will be any going back for me ever," Egwene said, sighing, sinking down on her bed. She gestured to the rocks on the table. "Renna gave me a test, yesterday. I picked out the piece of iron ore, and the copper ore, blindfolded, every time she mixed them up. She left them all here to remind me of my success. She seemed to think it was some kind of reward to be reminded."

"ɪt dʌzn sim ɛni wɝs ðən ðə ɹɛst - nɑt nɪɹli əz bæɾ əz meɪkɪŋ θɪŋz ɪksploʊd laɪk faɪɹwɝks - bʌt kʊdn juv laɪd? toʊld əɹ jə dɪdnt noʊ wɪtʃ wɑz wɪtʃ?"

"It doesn't seem any worse than the rest - not nearly as bad as making things explode like fireworks - but couldn't you have lied? Told her you didn't know which was which?"

"ju stɪl də nɑt noʊ wʌt ðɪs ɪz laɪk." ɛɡwin tʌɡd ət ðə kɑlɝ; pʊlɪŋ dɪd noʊ mɔɹ ɡʊd ðən tʃænəlɪŋ hæd. "wɛn ɹɛnə ɪz wɛɹɪŋ ðət bɹeɪslət, ʃi noʊz wʌɾ aɪm duɪŋ wɪð ðə paʊɝ, ən wʌɾ aɪm nɑt. səmtaɪmz ʃi ivən simz tə noʊ wən ʃi ɪzənt wɛɹɪŋ ɪt; ʃi sɛz sʌldəm dɪvɛləp - ən əfɪnəɾi, ʃi kɔlz ɪt - æftɝ ə waɪl." ʃi saɪd. "noʊ wʌn ivən θɔt tə tɛs mi ɑn ðɪs ɝliɝ. ɝθ ɪz wʌn ə ðə faɪv paʊɝz ðət wɑz stʃɹɔŋɡəst ɪn mɛn. wən aɪ pɪkt aʊt ðoʊz ɹɑks, ʃi tʊk mi aʊtsaɪd ðə taʊn, ən aɪ wɑz eɪbəl tə pɔɪn ɹaɪt tə ən əbændən aɪɝn maɪn. ɪt wɑz ɔl oʊvɝɡɹoʊn, ən ðəɹ wɑzn ɛni oʊpənɪŋ tə bi sin əɾ ɔl, bʌt wʌns aɪ nu haʊ, aɪ kəd fil ði aɪɝn ɔɹ stɪl ɪn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ðəɹ hæzən bɪn ɪnʌf tə meɪk ɪt wɝθ wɝkɪŋ ɪn ə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz, bʌɾ aɪ nu ɪt wɑz ðɛɹ. aɪ kʊdn laɪ tə hɝ, mɪn. ʃi nu aɪ hæd sɛns ðə maɪn əz sun əz aɪ dɪd. ʃi wɑz soʊ ɪksaɪɾəd, ʃi pɹɑməs mi ə pʊɾɪŋ wɪð maɪ sʌpɝ." ʃi fɛlt əɹ tʃiks ɡɹoʊɪŋ hɑt, ɪn æŋɡɝ ən ɪmbɛɹəsmənt. "əpɛɹənli," ʃi sɛd bɪɾɝli, "aɪ æm naʊ tu væljəbəl tə bi weɪstəd meɪkɪŋ θɪŋz ɪksploʊd. ɛni deɪmeɪn kən də ðæt; oʊnli ə hændfʊl kən faɪn ɔɹz ɪn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. laɪt, aɪ heɪt meɪkɪŋ θɪŋz ɪksploʊd, bʌɾ aɪ wɪʃ ðət wɑz ɔl aɪ kəd du."

"You still do not know what this is like." Egwene tugged at the collar; pulling did no more good than channeling had. "When Renna is wearing that bracelet, she knows what I am doing with the Power, and what I am not. Sometimes she even seems to know when she isn't wearing it; she says sul'dam develop - an affinity, she calls it - after a while." She sighed. "No one even thought to test me on this earlier. Earth is one of the Five Powers that was strongest in men. When I picked out those rocks, she took me outside the town, and I was able to point right to an abandoned iron mine. It was all overgrown, and there wasn't any opening to be seen at all, but once I knew how, I could feel the iron ore still in the ground. There hasn't been enough to make it worth working in a hundred years, but I knew it was there. I couldn't lie to her, Min. She knew I had sensed the mine as soon as I did. She was so excited, she promised me a pudding with my supper." She felt her cheeks growing hot, in anger and embarrassment. "Apparently," she said bitterly, "I am now too valuable to be wasted making things explode. Any damane can do that; only a handful can find ores in the ground. Light, I hate making things explode, but I wish that was all I could do."

ðə kʌlɝ ɪn əɹ tʃiks dipənd. ʃi dɪd heɪɾ ɪt, meɪkɪŋ tʃɹiz tɛɹ ðɛmsɛlvz tə splɪntɝz ən ði ɝθ ɪɹʌpt; ðət wɑz mɛn fəɹ bæɾəl, fəɹ kɪlɪŋ, ən ʃi wɑntəd noʊ pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt. jɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ ðə sintʃæn lɛɾ əɹ də wɑz ənʌðɝ tʃæns tə tʌtʃ seɪaɪdɑɹ, tə fil ðə paʊɝ floʊɪŋ θɹu hɝ. ʃi heɪɾəd ðə θɪŋz ɹɛnə ən ði ʌðɝ sʌldəm meɪɾ əɹ du, bʌt ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ðət ʃi kəd hændəl mʌtʃ mɔɹ ə ðə paʊɝ naʊ ðən ʃi kəd bɪfɔɹ livɪŋ tɑɹ vəlɑn. ʃi sɝɾənli nu ʃi kəd də θɪŋz wɪð ɪt ðət noʊ sɪstɝ ɪn ðə taʊɝ hæɾ ɛvɝ θɔɾ ə duɪŋ; ðeɪ nɛvɝ θɔɾ ə tɛɹɪŋ ði ɝθ əpɑɹt tə kɪl mɛn.

The color in her cheeks deepened. She did hate it, making trees tear themselves to splinters and the earth erupt; that was meant for battle, for killing, and she wanted no part of it. Yet anything the Seanchan let her do was another chance to touch saidar, to feel the Power flowing through her. She hated the things Renna and the other sul'dam made her do, but she was sure that she could handle much more of the Power now than she could before leaving Tar Valon. She certainly knew she could do things with it that no sister in the Tower had ever thought of doing; they never thought of tearing the earth apart to kill men.

"pɝhæps jə woʊn əv tə wɝi əbaʊɾ ɛni ʌv ɪt mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ," mɪn sɛd, ɡɹɪnɪŋ. "aɪv faʊn əs ə ʃɪp, ɛɡwin. ðə kæptən əz bɪn hɛl hɪɹ baɪ ðə sintʃæn, ən hiz əbaʊt ɹɛɾi tə seɪl wɪð əɹ wɪθaʊt pɝmɪʃən."

"Perhaps you won't have to worry about any of it much longer," Min said, grinning. "I've found us a ship, Egwene. The captain has been held here by the Seanchan, and he is about ready to sail with or without permission."

"ɪf hɪl teɪk ju, mɪn, ɡoʊ wɪð hɪm," ɛɡwin sɛd wɛɹəli. "aɪ toʊl jə aɪm væljəbəl, naʊ. ɹɛnə sɛz ɪn ə fju deɪz ðəɹ sɛndɪŋ ə ʃɪp bæk tə sintʃæn. dʒʌs tə teɪk mi."

"If he will take you, Min, go with him," Egwene said wearily. "I told you I'm valuable, now. Renna says in a few days they're sending a ship back to Seanchan. Just to take me."

mɪnz ɡɹɪn vænɪʃt, ən ðeɪ stɛɹɾ əɾ itʃ ʌðɝ. sʌɾənli mɪn hɝld əɹ ɹɑk ət ðə paɪl ɑn ðə teɪbəl, skæɾɝɪŋ ðɛm. "ðɛɹ əz tə bi ə weɪ aʊɾ ə hɪɹ. ðəɹ əz tə bi ə weɪ tə teɪk ðət blʌɾi θɪŋ ɔf jəɹ nɛk!"

Min's grin vanished, and they stared at each other. Suddenly Min hurled her rock at the pile on the table, scattering them. "There has to be a way out of here. There has to be a way to take that bloody thing off your neck!"

ɛɡwin lin əɹ hɛd bæk əɡɛns ðə wɔl. "ju noʊ ðə sintʃæn əv kəlɛktəɾ ɛvɹi wʊmən ðeɪv bɪn eɪbəl tə faɪn u kən tʃænəl ivən ə spɛk. ðeɪ kʌm fɹəm ɔl oʊvɝ, nɑt dʒʌs fɹəm hɪɹ ɪn fɑlm, bʌt fɹəm ðə fɪʃɪŋ vɪlədʒəz, ən fɹəm fɑɹmɪŋ taʊnz ɪnlænd. tæɹɑbənɝ ən dəmɑni wɪmən, pæsənʒɝz ɔf ʃɪps ðeɪv stɑpt. ðəɹ ɑɹ tu ɛɛs sədaɪ əmʌŋ ðɛm."

Egwene leaned her head back against the wall. "You know the Seanchan have collected every woman they've been able to find who can channel even a speck. They come from all over, not just from here in Falme, but from the fishing villages, and from farming towns inland. Taraboner and Domani women, passengers off ships they've stopped. There are two Aes Sedai among them."

"ɛɛs sədaɪ!" mɪn ɪkskleɪmd. baɪ hæbət ʃi lʊkt ɝaʊn tə meɪk ʃʊɹ noʊ sintʃæn hæɾ oʊvɝhɝɾ əɹ seɪɪŋ ðət neɪm. "ɛɡwin, ɪf ðəɹ ɑɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ hɪɹ, ðeɪ kən hɛlp ʌs. lemi tɔk tə ðɛm, ən - "

"Aes Sedai!" Min exclaimed. By habit she looked around to make sure no Seanchan had overheard her saying that name. "Egwene, if there are Aes Sedai here, they can help us. Let me talk to them, and - "

"ðeɪ kæn ivən hɛlp ðɛmsɛlvz, mɪn. aɪ oʊnli tɔk tə wʌn - hɝ neɪm ɪz ɹaɪmə; ðə sʌldəm doʊn kɔl əɹ ðæt, bʌt ðæts əɹ neɪm; ʃi wɑntəd tə meɪk ʃʊɹ aɪ nu ɪt - ən ʃi toʊl mi ðəɹ ɪz ənʌðɝ. ʃi toʊl mi ɪn bɪtwin baʊts ə tɪɹz. ʃiz ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən ʃi wɑz kɹaɪɪŋ, mɪn! ʃiz ə kɑlɝ ɑn əɹ nɛk, ðeɪ meɪk əɹ ænsɝ tə pʊɹə, ən ʃi kæn də ɛniθɪŋ mɔɹ əbaʊɾ ɪt ðən aɪ kæn. ðeɪ kæptʃɝɾ əɹ wən fɑlm fɛl. ʃi wɑz kɹaɪɪŋ kəz ʃiz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə stɑp faɪɾɪŋ əɡɛnst ɪt, kəz ʃi kænɑt teɪk biɪŋ pʌnɪʃt ɛnimɔɹ. ʃi wɑz kɹaɪɪŋ kəz ʃi wɑns tə teɪk əɹ oʊn laɪf, ən ʃi kænɑɾ ivən də ðət wɪθaʊt pɝmɪʃən. laɪt, aɪ noʊ haʊ ʃi filz!"

"They can't even help themselves, Min. I only talked to one - her name is Ryma; the sul'dam don't call her that, but that's her name; she wanted to make sure I knew it - and she told me there is another. She told me in between bouts of tears. She's Aes Sedai, and she was crying, Min! She has a collar on her neck, they make her answer to Pura, and she can't do anything more about it than I can. They captured her when Falme fell. She was crying because she's beginning to stop fighting against it, because she cannot take being punished anymore. She was crying because she wants to take her own life, and she cannot even do that without permission. Light, I know how she feels!"

mɪn ʃɪftəɾ ənizəli, smuðɪŋ əɹ dʒɹɛs wɪð sʌɾənli nɝvəs hænz. "ɛɡwin, jə doʊnt wɑn tə. . . . ɛɡwin, jə mʌs nɑt θɪŋk ə hɑɹmɪŋ jɝsɛlf. əl ɡɛt jə aʊt sʌmhaʊ. aɪ wɪl!"

Min shifted uneasily, smoothing her dress with suddenly nervous hands. "Egwene, you don't want to. . . . Egwene, you must not think of harming yourself. I will get you out somehow. I will!"

"aɪ æm nɑt gɑnə kɪl maɪsɛlf," ɛɡwin sɛd dʒɹaɪli. "ivən ɪf aɪ kʊd. lemi hæv jəɹ naɪf. kʌm ɑn. aɪ woʊn hɝt maɪsɛlf. dʒʌs hæn ɪt tə mi."

"I am not going to kill myself," Egwene said dryly. "Even if I could. Let me have your knife. Come on. I won't hurt myself. Just hand it to me."

mɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd bɪfɔɹ sloʊli teɪkɪŋ əɹ naɪf fɹəm ɪts ʃiθ əɾ əɹ weɪst. ʃi hɛld ɪɾ aʊt wɛɹəli, ɑbviəsli ɹɛɾi tə lip ɪf ɛɡwin tʃɹaɪɾ ɛniθɪŋ.

Min hesitated before slowly taking her knife from its sheath at her waist. She held it out warily, obviously ready to leap if Egwene tried anything.

ɛɡwin tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ ən ɹitʃt fəɹ ðə hɪlt. ə sɑf kwɪvɝ ɹæn θɹu ðə mʌsəlz ə hɝ ɑɹm. əz əɹ hæn keɪm wɪðɪn ə fʊɾ ə ðə naɪf, ə kɹæmp sʌɾənli kəntɔɹɾəd əɹ fɪŋɡɝz. aɪz fɪkst, ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə fɔɹs əɹ hæn kloʊsɝ. ðə kɹæmp sizd əɹ hoʊl ɑɹm, nɑɾɪŋ mʌsəlz tə hɝ ʃoʊldɝ. wɪð ə ɡɹoʊn, ʃi sæŋk bæk, ɹʌbɪŋ əɹ ɑɹm ən kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾɪŋ əɹ θɔts ɑn nɑt tʌtʃɪŋ ðə naɪf. sloʊli, ðə peɪn bɪɡæn tə lɛsən.

Egwene took a deep breath and reached for the hilt. A soft quiver ran through the muscles of her arm. As her hand came within a foot of the knife, a cramp suddenly contorted her fingers. Eyes fixed, she tried to force her hand closer. The cramp seized her whole arm, knotting muscles to her shoulder. With a groan, she sank back, rubbing her arm and concentrating her thoughts on not touching the knife. Slowly, the pain began to lessen.

mɪn stɛɹɾ əɾ əɹ ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli. "wʌt . . . ? aɪ doʊn ʌndɝstænd."

Min stared at her incredulously. "What . . . ? I don't understand."

"deɪmeɪn ɑɹ nɑɾ əlaʊd tə tʌtʃ ə wɛpən ʌv ɛni kaɪnd." ʃi wɝkt əɹ ɑɹm, filɪŋ ðə taɪtnəs ɡoʊ. "ivən əɹ miɾ ɪz kʌt fəɹ ʌs. aɪ doʊnt wɑnə hɝt maɪsɛlf, bʌɾ aɪ kəd nɑɾ ɪf aɪ dɪd wɑn tə. noʊ deɪmeɪn ɪz ɛvɝ lɛft əloʊn wɛɹ ʃi maɪt dʒʌmp fɹəm ə haɪt - ðət wɪndoʊ ɪz neɪld ʃʌt - əɹ θɹoʊ hɝsɛlf ɪn ə ɹɪvɝ."

"Damane are not allowed to touch a weapon of any kind." She worked her arm, feeling the tightness go. "Even our meat is cut for us. I don't want to hurt myself, but I could not if I did want to. No damane is ever left alone where she might jump from a height - that window is nailed shut - or throw herself in a river."

"wɛl, ðæts ə ɡʊd θɪŋ. aɪ min. . . . oʊ, aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌɾ aɪ min. ɪf jə kəd dʒʌmp ɪn ə ɹɪvɝ, jə maɪɾ ɪskeɪp."

"Well, that's a good thing. I mean. . . . Oh, I don't know what I mean. If you could jump in a river, you might escape."

ɛɡwin wɛn ɑn dʌli, əz ɪf ði ʌðɝ wʊmən hæd nɑt spoʊkən. "ðeɪ ɑɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ mi, mɪn. ðə sʌldəm ən ði æɾəm ɑɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ mi. aɪ kænɑt tʌtʃ ɛniθɪŋ aɪ ivən θɪŋk ʌv əz ə wɛpən. ə fju wiks əɡoʊ aɪ kənsɪɾɝd hɪɾɪŋ ɹɛnə oʊvɝ ðə hɛd wɪð ðət pɪtʃɝ, ən aɪ kəd nɑt pɔɹ wɑʃ wɔɾɝ fəɹ θɹi deɪz. wʌns aɪd θɔɾ ʌv ɪt ðət weɪ, aɪ nɑɾ oʊnli hæd tə stɑp θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt hɪɾɪŋ əɹ wɪð ɪt, aɪ hæd tə kənvɪns maɪsɛlf aɪ wəd nɛvɝ, ʌndɝ ɛni sɝkəmstænsəz, hɪɾ əɹ wɪð ɪt bɪfɔɹ aɪ kəd tʌtʃ ɪɾ əɡɛn. ʃi nu wʌt hæd hæpənd, toʊl mi wʌɾ aɪ hæd tə du, ən wəd nɑt lemi wɑʃ ɛniwɛɹ ɪksɛpt wɪð ðət pɪtʃɝ ən boʊl. jə ɑɹ lʌki ɪt hæpən bɪtwin jəɹ vɪzəɾɪŋ deɪz. ɹɛnə meɪd ʃʊɹ aɪ spɛn ðoʊz deɪz swɛɾɪŋ fɹəm ðə taɪm aɪ woʊk tə ðə taɪm aɪ fɛl əslip, ɪɡzɔstəd. aɪm tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪt ðɛm, bʌt ðeɪ ɑɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ mi əz ʃʊɹli əz ðəɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ pʊɹə." ʃi klæpt ə hæn tə hɝ maʊθ, moʊnɪŋ θɹu hɝ tiθ. "hɝ neɪm ɪz ɹaɪmə. aɪ hæv tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ əɹ neɪm, nɑt ðə neɪm ðeɪv pʊɾ ɑn hɝ. ʃiz ɹaɪmə, ən ʃiz jɛloʊ ədʒɑ, ən ʃiz fɔɾ əm əz lɔŋ ən əz hɑɹɾ əz ʃi kʊd. ɪts noʊ fɔlt ə hɝz ðət ʃi hæzən ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ lɛf tə faɪɾ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. aɪ wɪʃ aɪ nu hu ði ʌðɝ sɪstɝ ɪz ðət ɹaɪmə mɛnʃənd. aɪ wɪʃ aɪ nu hɝ neɪm. ɹɪmɛmbɝ boʊθ ʌv ʌs, mɪn. ɹaɪmə, ʌv ðə jɛloʊ ədʒɑ, ən ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ. nɑɾ ɛɡwin ðə deɪmeɪn; ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ ʌv ɛmənz fild. wɪl jə də ðæt?"

Egwene went on dully, as if the other woman had not spoken. "They are training me, Min. The sul'dam and the a'dam are training me. I cannot touch anything I even think of as a weapon. A few weeks ago I considered hitting Renna over the head with that pitcher, and I could not pour wash water for three days. Once I'd thought of it that way, I not only had to stop thinking about hitting her with it, I had to convince myself I would never, under any circumstances, hit her with it before I could touch it again. She knew what had happened, told me what I had to do, and would not let me wash anywhere except with that pitcher and bowl. You are lucky it happened between your visiting days. Renna made sure I spent those days sweating from the time I woke to the time I fell asleep, exhausted. I am trying to fight them, but they are training me as surely as they're training Pura." She clapped a hand to her mouth, moaning through her teeth. "Her name is Ryma. I have to remember her name, not the name they've put on her. She is Ryma, and she's Yellow Ajah, and she has fought them as long and as hard as she could. It is no fault of hers that she hasn't the strength left to fight any longer. I wish I knew who the other sister is that Ryma mentioned. I wish I knew her name. Remember both of us, Min. Ryma, of the Yellow Ajah, and Egwene al'Vere. Not Egwene the damane; Egwene al'Vere of Emond's Field. Will you do that?"

"stɑp ɪt!" mɪn snæpt. "ju stɑp ɪt ɹaɪt ðɪs ɪnstənt! ɪf jə ɡɛt ʃɪpt ɔf tə sintʃæn, əl bi ɹaɪt ðəɹ wɪð ju. bʌɾ aɪ doʊn θɪŋk jə wɪl. jə noʊ aɪv ɹɛd ju, ɛɡwin. aɪ doʊn ʌndɝstæn moʊst ʌv ɪt - aɪ ɔlmoʊs nɛvɝ də - bʌɾ aɪ si θɪŋz aɪm ʃʊɹ lɪŋk jə tə ɹænd, ən pɛɹɪn, ən mæt, ən - jɛs, ivən ɡɑləd, ðə laɪt hɛlp jə fəɹ ə ful. haʊ kən ɛni ʌv ðət hæpən ɪf ðə sintʃæn teɪk jə ɔf əkɹɔs ði oʊʃən?"

"Stop it!" Min snapped. "You stop it right this instant! If you get shipped off to Seanchan, I'll be right there with you. But I don't think you will. You know I've read you, Egwene. I don't understand most of it - I almost never do - but I see things I am sure link you to Rand, and Perrin, and Mat, and - yes, even Galad, the Light help you for a fool. How can any of that happen if the Seanchan take you off across the ocean?"

"meɪbi ðəɹ gɑnə kɑŋkɝ ðə hoʊl wɝld, mɪn. ɪf ðeɪ kɑŋkɝ ðə wɝld, ðɛɹz noʊ ɹizən ɹænd ən ɡɑləɾ ən ðə ɹɛs kəd nɑɾ ɛn ʌp ɪn sintʃæn."

"Maybe they're going to conquer the whole world, Min. If they conquer the world, there's no reason Rand and Galad and the rest could not end up in Seanchan."

"ju nɪni-hɛɾəd ɡus!"

"You ninny-headed goose!"

"aɪ æm biɪŋ pɹæktəkəl," ɛɡwin sɛd ʃɑɹpli. "aɪ doʊn ɪntɛn tə stɑp faɪɾɪŋ, nɑɾ əz lɔŋ əz aɪ kən bɹið, bʌɾ aɪ doʊn si ɛni hoʊp ðəɾ əl ɛvɝ əv ði æɾəm ɔf mi, iðɝ. dʒʌst əz aɪ doʊn si ɛni hoʊp ðəɾ ɛniwʌn ɪz gɑnə stɑp ðə sintʃæn. mɪn, ɪf ðɪs ʃɪp kæptən wɪl teɪk ju, ɡoʊ wɪð hɪm. ət lis ðən wʌn ʌv əs wɪl bi fɹi."

"I am being practical," Egwene said sharply. "I don't intend to stop fighting, not as long as I can breathe, but I don't see any hope that I'll ever have the a'dam off me, either. Just as I don't see any hope that anyone is going to stop the Seanchan. Min, if this ship captain will take you, go with him. At least then one of us will be free."

ðə dɔɹ swʌŋ oʊpən, ən ɹɛnə stɛpt ɪn.

The door swung open, and Renna stepped in.

ɛɡwin dʒʌmp tə hɝ fiɾ ən baʊd ʃɑɹpli, əz dɪd mɪn. ðə taɪni ɹum wɑz kɹaʊɾəd fəɹ boʊɪŋ, bʌt sintʃæn ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn pɹoʊɾəkɑl bɪfɔɹ kʌmfɝt.

Egwene jumped to her feet and bowed sharply, as did Min. The tiny room was crowded for bowing, but Seanchan insisted on protocol before comfort.

"jɔɹ vɪzəɾɪŋ deɪ, ɪz ɪt?" ɹɛnə sɛd. "aɪ hæd fɝɡɑɾən. wɛl, ðəɹ ɪz tʃɹeɪnɪŋ tə bi dʌn ivən ɑn vɪzəɾɪŋ deɪz."

"Your visiting day, is it?" Renna said. "I had forgotten. Well, there is training to be done even on visiting days."

ɛɡwin wɑtʃt ʃɑɹpli əz ðə sʌldəm tʊk daʊn ðə bɹeɪslət, oʊpən ɪt, ən fæsən ɪɾ əɡɛn ɝaʊn əɹ ɹɪst. ʃi kəd nɑt si haʊ ɪt wɑz dʌn. ɪf ʃi cʊɾə pɹoʊbd wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ, ʃi wəd hæv, bʌt ɹɛnə wʊɾə noʊn ðəɾ ɪmiɾiətli. əz ðə bɹeɪslət kloʊzd ɝaʊn ɹɛnəz ɹɪst ə lʊk keɪm ɑntu ðə sʌldəmz feɪs ðət meɪɾ ɛɡwinz hɑɹt sɪŋk.

Egwene watched sharply as the sul'dam took down the bracelet, opened it, and fastened it again around her wrist. She could not see how it was done. If she could have probed with the One Power, she would have, but Renna would have known that immediately. As the bracelet closed around Renna's wrist a look came onto the sul'dam's face that made Egwene's heart sink.

"ju hæv bɪn tʃænəlɪŋ." ɹɛnəz vɔɪs wɑz dɪsɛptɪvli maɪld; ðəɹ wɑz ə spɑɹk ʌv æŋɡɝ ɪn əɹ aɪz. "ju noʊ ðəɾ ɪz fɔɹbɪɾən ɪksɛpt wən wəɹ kəmplit." ɛɡwin wɛɾ əɹ lɪps. "pɝhæps aɪ hæv bɪn tu liniənt wɪð ju. pɝhæps jə bɪliv ðət kəz jə ɑɹ væljəbəl naʊ, jəl bi əlaʊd laɪsəns. aɪ θɪŋk aɪ meɪɾ ə mɪsteɪk lɛɾɪŋ jə kip jəɹ oʊl neɪm. aɪ hæɾ ə kɪɾən kɔl tuli wən aɪ wɑz ə tʃaɪld. fɹəm naʊ ɑn, jəɹ neɪm ɪz tuli. jəl ɡoʊ naʊ, mɪn. jəɹ vɪzəɾɪŋ deɪ wɪð tuli ɪz ɛndəd."

"You have been channeling." Renna's voice was deceptively mild; there was a spark of anger in her eyes. "You know that is forbidden except when we are complete." Egwene wet her lips. "Perhaps I have been too lenient with you. Perhaps you believe that because you are valuable now, you will be allowed license. I think I made a mistake letting you keep your old name. I had a kitten called Tuli when I was a child. From now on, your name is Tuli. You will go now, Min. Your visiting day with Tuli is ended."

mɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd oʊnli lɔŋ ɪnʌf fəɹ wʌn æŋɡwɪʃt lʊk əɾ ɛɡwin bɪfɔɹ livɪŋ. nʌθɪŋ mɪn kəd seɪ əɹ də wəd də ɛniθɪŋ ɪksɛp meɪk mæɾɝz wɝs, bʌɾ ɛɡwin kəd nɑt hɛlp lʊkɪŋ lɔŋɪŋli ət ðə dɔɹ əz ɪt kloʊz bɪhaɪn əɹ fɹɛnd.

Min hesitated only long enough for one anguished look at Egwene before leaving. Nothing Min could say or do would do anything except make matters worse, but Egwene could not help looking longingly at the door as it closed behind her friend.

ɹɛnə tʊk ðə tʃɛɹ, fɹaʊnɪŋ əɾ ɛɡwin. "aɪ mʌs pʌnɪʃ jə səvɪɹli fəɹ ðɪs. wɪl boʊθ bi kɔl tə ðə kɔɹɾ ə ðə naɪn munz - jə fəɹ wʌt jə kən du; aɪ əz jəɹ sʌldəm ən tʃɹeɪnɝ - ən əl nɑɾ əlaʊ jə tə dɪsɡɹeɪs mi ɪn ði aɪz ə ði ɛmpɹɛs. əl stɑp wən jə tɛl mi haʊ mʌtʃ jə lʌv biɪŋ deɪmeɪn ən haʊ oʊbiɾiənt jəl bi æftɝ ðɪs. ænd, tuli. meɪk mi bɪliv ɛvɹi wɝd."

Renna took the chair, frowning at Egwene. "I must punish you severely for this. We will both be called to the Court of the Nine Moons - you for what you can do; I as your sul'dam and trainer - and I will not allow you to disgrace me in the eyes of the Empress. I will stop when you tell me how much you love being damane and how obedient you will be after this. And, Tuli. Make me believe every word."


tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾiθɹi


CHAPTER 43

eɪ plæn


A Plan

aʊtsaɪɾ ɪn ðə loʊ-silɪŋɡd hɔlweɪ, mɪn dʌɡ hɝ neɪlz ɪndə hɝ pɑmz ət ðə fɝs pɪɹsɪŋ kɹaɪ fɹəm ðə ɹum. ʃi tʊk ə stɛp təwɔɹd ðə dɔɹ bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd stɑp hɝsɛlf, ən wən ʃi dɪd stɑp, tɪɹz spɹæŋ ʌp ɪn əɹ aɪz. laɪt hɛlp mi, ɔl aɪ kən də ɪz meɪk ɪt wɝs. ɛɡwin, aɪm sɑɹi. aɪm sɑɹi.

Outside in the low-ceilinged hallway, Min dug her nails into her palms at the first piercing cry from the room. She took a step toward the door before she could stop herself, and when she did stop, tears sprang up in her eyes. Light help me, all I can do is make it worse. Egwene, I'm sorry. I'm sorry.

filɪŋ wɝs ðən jusləs, ʃi pɪkt ʌp əɹ skɝts ən ɹæn, ən ɛɡwinz skɹimz pɝsud hɝ. ʃi kəd nɑt meɪk hɝsɛlf steɪ, ən livɪŋ meɪɾ əɹ fil ə kaʊɝd. hæf blaɪnd wɪð wipɪŋ, ʃi faʊn hɝsɛlf ɪn ðə stʃɹit bɪfɔɹ ʃi nu ɪt. ʃi hæɾ ɪntɛndəd tə ɡoʊ bæk tə hɝ ɹum, bʌt naʊ ʃi kəd nɑt də ɪt. ʃi kəd nɑt stæn ðə θɔt ðəɾ ɛɡwin wɑz biɪŋ hɝt waɪl ʃi sæt wɔɹm ən seɪf ʌndɝ ðə nɛkst ɹuf. skɹʌbɪŋ ðə tɪɹz fɹəm əɹ aɪz, ʃi swɛpt əɹ kloʊk ɝaʊn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz ən stɑɹɾəd daʊn ðə stʃɹit. ɛvɹi taɪm ʃi klɪɹɾ əɹ aɪz, nu tɪɹz bɪɡæn tʃɹɪklɪŋ əlɔŋ əɹ tʃiks. ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əkʌstəm tə wipɪŋ oʊpənli, bʌt ðən ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əkʌstəm tə filɪŋ soʊ hɛlpləs, soʊ jusləs. ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ wɛɹ ʃi wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ, oʊnli ðəɾ ɪt hæd tə bi əz fɑɹ əz ʃi kəd ɹitʃ fɹəm ɛɡwinz kɹaɪz.

Feeling worse than useless, she picked up her skirts and ran, and Egwene's screams pursued her. She could not make herself stay, and leaving made her feel a coward. Half blind with weeping, she found herself in the street before she knew it. She had intended to go back to her room, but now she could not do it. She could not stand the thought that Egwene was being hurt while she sat warm and safe under the next roof. Scrubbing the tears from her eyes, she swept her cloak around her shoulders and started down the street. Every time she cleared her eyes, new tears began trickling along her cheeks. She was not accustomed to weeping openly, but then she was not accustomed to feeling so helpless, so useless. She did not know where she was going, only that it had to be as far as she could reach from Egwene's cries.

"mɪn!"

"Min!"

ðə loʊ-pɪtʃt ʃaʊt bɹɔɾ əɹ ʌp ʃɔɹt. ət fɝst, ʃi kəd nɑt meɪk aʊɾ u hæd kɔld. ɹɛləɾɪvli fju pipəl wɔk ðə stʃɹit ðɪs kloʊs tə wɛɹ ðə deɪmeɪn wɝ haʊzd. əsaɪd fɹəm ə loʊn mæn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɪntʃɹəs tu sintʃæn soʊlʒɝz ɪn baɪɪŋ ðə pɪktʃɝ i wəd dʒɹɔ ʌv əm wɪð ɪz kʌlɝd tʃɔks, ɛvɹiwʌn loʊkəl tʃɹaɪd tə stɛp əlɔŋ kwɪkli wɪθaʊɾ æktʃəli  əpɪɹɪŋ tə ɹʌn. ə pɛɹ ə sʌldəm stʃɹoʊl baɪ, deɪmeɪn tʃɹeɪlɪŋ bɪhaɪnd wɪð aɪz daʊn; ðə sintʃæn wɪmən wɝ tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt haʊ mɛni mɔɹ mɛɹəθdəmeɪn ðeɪ ɪkspɛktəd tə faɪn bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ seɪld. mɪnz aɪz pæst ɹaɪɾ oʊvɝ ðə tu wɪmən ɪn lɔŋ flis koʊts, ðən swʌŋ bæk ɪn wʌndɝ əz ðeɪ keɪm təwɔɹd hɝ. "nɪneɪiv? ɪleɪn?"

The low-pitched shout brought her up short. At first, she could not make out who had called. Relatively few people walked the street this close to where the damane were housed. Aside from a lone man trying to interest two Seanchan soldiers in buying the picture he would draw of them with his colored chalks, everyone local tried to step along quickly without actually appearing to run. A pair of sul'dam strolled by, damane trailing behind with eyes down; the Seanchan women were talking about how many more marath'damane they expected to find before they sailed. Min's eyes passed right over the two women in long fleece coats, then swung back in wonder as they came toward her. "Nynaeve? Elayne?"

"nʌn ʌðɝ." nɪneɪivz smaɪl wɑz stʃɹeɪnd; boʊθ wɪmən hæd taɪɾ aɪz, əz ɪf ðeɪ fɔt wɝid fɹaʊnz. mɪn θɔt ʃi hæd nɛvɝ sin ɛniθɪŋ əz wʌndɝfəl əz ðə saɪɾ ə ðɛm. "ðæt kʌlɝ bɪkʌmz ju," nɪneɪiv kəntɪnjud. "ju ʃʊɾə teɪkən ʌp dʒɹɛsəz lɔŋ sɪns. ðoʊ aɪv θɔɾ ə bɹitʃɪz maɪsɛlf sɪns aɪ sɔ ðɛm ɑn ju." hɝ vɔɪs ʃɑɹpən əz ʃi dʒɹu kloʊs ɪnʌf tə si mɪnz feɪs. "wʌɾ ɪz ðə mæɾɝ?"

"None other." Nynaeve's smile was strained; both women had tight eyes, as if they fought worried frowns. Min thought she had never seen anything as wonderful as the sight of them. "That color becomes you," Nynaeve continued. "You should have taken up dresses long since. Though I've thought of breeches myself since I saw them on you." Her voice sharpened as she drew close enough to see Min's face. "What is the matter?"

"juv bɪn kɹaɪɪŋ," ɪleɪn sɛd. "hæz sʌmθɪŋ hæpən tə ɛɡwin?"

"You've been crying," Elayne said. "Has something happened to Egwene?"

mɪn ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ ən lʊk bæk oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. ə sʌldəm ən deɪmeɪn keɪm daʊn ðə stɛps ʃi hæd juzd ən tɝn ði ʌðɝ weɪ, təwɔɹd ðə steɪbəlz ən hɔɹs jɑɹdz. ənʌðɝ wʊmən wɪð ðə laɪtnɪŋ pænəlz ɑn əɹ dʒɹɛs stʊɾ ət ðə tɑp ə ðə stɛɹz tɔkɪŋ wɪð sʌmwʌn stɪl ɪnsaɪd. mɪn ɡɹæbd əɹ fɹɛnz baɪ ði ɑɹmz ən hɝiɾ əm daʊn ðə stʃɹit təwɔɹd ðə hɑɹbɝ. "ɪts deɪnʒɝəs fəɹ jə tu hɪɹ. laɪt, ɪts deɪnʒɝəs fəɹ jə tə bi ɪn fɑlm. ðəɹ ɑɹ deɪmeɪn ɛvɹiwɛɹ, ən ɪf ðeɪ faɪn ju. . . . jə də noʊ wʌt deɪmeɪn ɑɹ? oʊ, jə doʊnt noʊ haʊ ɡʊɾ ɪts tə si jə boʊθ."

Min gave a start and looked back over her shoulder. A sul'dam and damane came down the steps she had used and turned the other way, toward the stables and horse yards. Another woman with the lightning panels on her dress stood at the top of the stairs talking with someone still inside. Min grabbed her friends by the arms and hurried them down the street toward the harbor. "It's dangerous for you two here. Light, it's dangerous for you to be in Falme. There are damane everywhere, and if they find you. . . . You do know what damane are? Oh, you don't know how good it is to see you both."

"aɪ ɪmædʒən əbaʊɾ əz hæf əz ɡʊɾ əz ɪts tə si ju," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "du jə noʊ wɛɹ ɛɡwin ɪz? ɪz ʃi ɪn wʌn ə ðoʊz bɪldɪŋz? ɪz ʃi ɔl ɹaɪt?"

"I imagine about as half as good as it is to see you," Nynaeve said. "Do you know where Egwene is? Is she in one of those buildings? Is she all right?"

mɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd ə fɹækʃən bɪfɔɹ seɪɪŋ, "ʃiz əz wɛl əz kən bi ɪkspɛktəd." mɪn kəd si ɪɾ ɔl tu wɛl, ɪf ʃi toʊld əm wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ tə ɛɡwin ɹaɪt ðət moʊmənt. nɪneɪiv wɑz əz laɪkli əz nɑt tə ɡoʊ stɔɹmɪŋ bæk ɪn ən ətɛmp tə stɑp ɪt. laɪt, lɛɾ ɪt bi oʊvɝ baɪ naʊ. laɪt, meɪk əɹ bɛn əɹ stʌbɝn nɛk dʒʌst wʌns bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ ɔlmoʊs bɹeɪk ɪt fɝst. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ haʊ tə ɡɛɾ əɹ aʊt, ðoʊ. aɪ faʊn ə ʃɪp kæptən u aɪ θɪŋk wɪl teɪk əs ɪf wi kən ɹitʃ ɪz ʃɪp wɪð əɹ - hi woʊn hɛlp ənlɛs wi meɪk ɪt ðət fɑɹ, ən aɪ kænɑt seɪ aɪ bleɪm ɪm - bʌɾ aɪ hæv noʊ aɪdiə haʊ tə də ivən ðət mʌtʃ."

Min hesitated a fraction before saying, "She's as well as can be expected." Min could see it all too well, if she told them what was happening to Egwene right that moment. Nynaeve was as likely as not to go storming back in an attempt to stop it. Light, let it be over by now. Light, make her bend her stubborn neck just once before they almost break it first. "I don't know how to get her out, though. I found a ship captain who I think will take us if we can reach his ship with her - he won't help unless we make it that far, and I cannot say I blame him - but I have no idea how to do even that much."

"ə ʃɪp," nɪneɪiv sɛd θɔtfəli. "aɪ hæd mɛn tə sɪmpli ɹaɪɾ ist, bʌɾ aɪ mʌst seɪ aɪv wɝiɾ əbaʊɾ ɪt. əz nɪɹli əz aɪ kən meɪk aʊt, wi wəɾ əv tə bi ɔlmoʊst ɔf toʊmən hɛd bɪfɔɹ wi wɝ klɪɹ ə sintʃæn pətʃɹoʊlz kəmplitli, ən ðən ðɛɹz səpoʊz tə bi faɪɾɪŋ ə səm sɔɹɾ ɑn ɑlməθ pleɪn. aɪ nɛvɝ θɔɾ ʌv ə ʃɪp. wɪv hɔɹsəz, ən wi də nɑɾ əv mʌni fəɹ pæsədʒ. haʊ mʌtʃ dʌz ðɪs mæn wɑnt?"

"A ship," Nynaeve said thoughtfully. "I had meant to simply ride east, but I must say I've worried about it. As nearly as I can make out, we would have to be almost off Toman Head before we were clear of Seanchan patrols completely, and then there's supposed to be fighting of some sort on Almoth Plain. I never thought of a ship. We have horses, and we do not have money for passage. How much does this man want?"

mɪn ʃɹʌɡd. "aɪ nɛvɝ ɡɑt ðət fɑɹ. wi doʊn əv ɛni mʌni, iðɝ. aɪ θɔɾ aɪ kəd pʊɾ ɔf peɪɪŋ əntɪl æftɝ wi seɪl. æftɝwɝdz . . . wɛl, aɪ doʊn θɪŋk hɪl pʊɾ ɪndə ɛni pɔɹt wɛɹ ðəɹ ɑɹ sintʃæn. wɛɹɛvɝ i θɹu əs ɔf, ɪt wəɾ əv tə bi bɛɾɝ ðən hɪɹ. ðə pɹɑbləm ɪz kənvɪnsɪŋ ɪm tə seɪl əɾ ɔl. hi wɑns tə, bʌt ðeɪ pətʃɹoʊl ɔf ðə hɑɹbɝ, tu, ən ðəɹ ɪz noʊ weɪ ʌv tɛlɪŋ ɪf ðɛɹz ə deɪmeɪn ɑn wʌn ə ðɛɹ ʃɪps əntɪl ɪts tu leɪt. 'ɡɪv mi ə deɪmeɪn ə maɪ oʊn ɑn maɪ dɛk,' hi sɛz, 'æn əl seɪl ðɪs ɪnstənt.' ðən i stɑɹts tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt dʒɹæfs ən ʃoʊlz ən li ʃɔɹz. aɪ doʊn ʌndɝstæn ɛni ʌv ðæt, bʌɾ əz lɔŋ əz aɪ smaɪl ən nɑɾ ɛvɹi naʊ ən ðɛn, hi kips tɔkɪŋ, ən aɪ θɪŋk ɪf aɪ kən kip ɪm tɔkɪŋ lɔŋ ɪnʌf, hɪl tɔk hɪmsɛlf ɪndə seɪlɪŋ." ʃi dʒɹu ə ʃʌɾɝɪŋ bɹɛθ; hɝ aɪz stɑɹɾəd stɪŋɪŋ əɡɛn. "oʊnli, aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðɛɹz taɪm tə lɛɾ ɪm tɔk hɪmsɛlf ɪndə ɪɾ ɛnimɔɹ. nɪneɪiv, ðəɹ gɑnə sɛn ɛɡwin bæk tə sintʃæn, ən sun."

Min shrugged. "I never got that far. We don't have any money, either. I thought I could put off paying until after we sail. Afterwards . . . well, I don't think he'll put into any port where there are Seanchan. Wherever he threw us off, it would have to be better than here. The problem is convincing him to sail at all. He wants to, but they patrol off the harbor, too, and there is no way of telling if there's a damane on one of their ships until it's too late. 'Give me a damane of my own on my deck,' he says, 'and I will sail this instant.' Then he starts talking about drafts and shoals and lee shores. I don't understand any of that, but as long as I smile and nod every now and then, he keeps talking, and I think if I can keep him talking long enough, he'll talk himself into sailing." She drew a shuddering breath; her eyes started stinging again. "Only, I don't think there's time to let him talk himself into it anymore. Nynaeve, they're going to send Egwene back to Seanchan, and soon."

ɪleɪn ɡæspt. "bʌt, waɪ?"

Elayne gasped. "But, why?"

"ʃi ɪz eɪbəl tə faɪn ɔɹ," mɪn sɛd mɪzɝəbli. "ə fju deɪz, ʃi sɛz, ən aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɪf ə fju deɪz ɪz ɪnʌf fəɹ ðɪs mæn tə kənvɪns hɪmsɛlf tə seɪl. ivən ɪf ɪɾ ɪz, haʊ də wi teɪk ðət ʃædoʊ-spɔn kɑlɝ ɔf hɝ? haʊ də wi ɡɛɾ əɹ aʊɾ ə ðə haʊs?"

"She is able to find ore," Min said miserably. "A few days, she says, and I don't know if a few days is enough for this man to convince himself to sail. Even if it is, how do we take that Shadow-spawned collar off her? How do we get her out of the house?"

"aɪ wɪʃ ɹænd wɝ hɪɹ." ɪleɪn saɪd, ən wən ðeɪ boʊθ lʊkt ət hɝ, ʃi blʌʃt ən kwɪkli æɾəd, "wɛl, hi dʌz əv ə sɔɹd. aɪ wɪʃ wi hæd sʌmbɑɾi wɪð ə sɔɹd. tɛn ə ðɛm. ə hʌnʒɹəd."

"I wish Rand were here." Elayne sighed, and when they both looked at her, she blushed and quickly added, "Well, he does have a sword. I wish we had somebody with a sword. Ten of them. A hundred."

"ɪɾ ɪzən sɔɹdz əɹ bɹɔn wi nid naʊ," nɪneɪiv sɛd, "bʌt bɹeɪnz. mɛn juʒəwəli θɪŋk wɪð ðə hɛɹ ɑn ðɛɹ tʃɛsts." ʃi tʌtʃt əɹ tʃɛst æbsənli, əz ɪf filɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ θɹu hɝ koʊt. "moʊst ə ðɛm du."

"It isn't swords or brawn we need now," Nynaeve said, "but brains. Men usually think with the hair on their chests." She touched her chest absently, as if feeling something through her coat. "Most of them do."

"wi wəd niɾ ən ɑɹmi," mɪn sɛd. "ə lɑɹdʒ ɑɹmi. ðə sintʃæn wɝ aʊtnʌmbɝd wən ðeɪ feɪs ðə tæɹɑbənɝz, ən ðə dəmɑni, ən ðeɪ wʌn ɛvɹi bæɾəl izəli, fɹəm wʌɾ aɪ hɪɹ." ʃi hɝidli pʊl nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn tə ði ɑpəzət saɪɾ ə ðə stʃɹiɾ əz ə deɪmeɪn ən sʌldəm klaɪm pæst əm ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd. ʃi wɑz ɹɪliv ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid fəɹ ɝdʒɪŋ; ði ʌðɝ tu wɑtʃt ðə lɪŋkt wɪmən ɡoʊ əz wɛɹəli əz ʃi. "sɪns wi doʊn əv ən ɑɹmi, ðə θɹi ʌv əs wɪl əv tə də ɪt. aɪ hoʊp wʌn ə jə kən θɪŋk ə sʌmθɪŋ aɪ hævənt; aɪv ɹæk maɪ bɹeɪnz, ən aɪ ɔlweɪz stʌmbəl wən ɪt kʌmz tə ði æɾəm, ðə liʃ ən kɑlɝ. sʌldəm doʊn laɪk ɛniwʌn wɑtʃɪŋ tu kloʊsli wən ðeɪ oʊpən ðɛm. aɪ θɪŋk aɪ kən ɡɛt jə ɪnsaɪd, ɪf ðət wɪl hɛlp. wʌn ə ju, ɛniweɪ. ðeɪ θɪŋk ə mi əz ə sɝvənt, bʌt sɝvəns meɪ hæv vɪzəɾɝz, əz lɔŋ əz ðeɪ kip tə ðə sɝvəns' kɔɹɾɝz."

"We would need an army," Min said. "A large army. The Seanchan were outnumbered when they faced the Taraboners, and the Domani, and they won every battle easily, from what I hear." She hurriedly pulled Nynaeve and Elayne to the opposite side of the street as a damane and sul'dam climbed past them on the other side. She was relieved there was no need for urging; the other two watched the linked women go as warily as she. "Since we don't have an army, the three of us will have to do it. I hope one of you can think of something I haven't; I've wracked my brains, and I always stumble when it comes to the a'dam, the leash and collar. Sul'dam don't like anyone watching too closely when they open them. I think I can get you inside, if that will help. One of you, anyway. They think of me as a servant, but servants may have visitors, as long as they keep to the servants' quarters."

nɪneɪiv wɔɹ ə θɔtfəl fɹaʊn, bʌɾ əɹ feɪs klɪɹɾ ɔlmoʊst ɪmiɾiətli, teɪkɪŋ ɑn ə pɝpəsfəl lʊk. "doʊn jə wɝi, mɪn. aɪ hæv ə fju aɪdiəz. aɪ hæv nɑt spɛn maɪ taɪm hɪɹ aɪdli. jə teɪk mi tə ðɪs mæn. ɪf hiz ɛni hɑɹɾɝ tə hændəl ðən ðə vɪlədʒ kaʊnsəl wɪð ðɛɹ bæks ʌp, əl it ðɪs koʊt."

Nynaeve wore a thoughtful frown, but her face cleared almost immediately, taking on a purposeful look. "Don't you worry, Min. I have a few ideas. I have not spent my time here idly. You take me to this man. If he is any harder to handle than the Village Council with their backs up, I will eat this coat."

ɪleɪn nɑɾəd, ɡɹɪnɪŋ, ən mɪn fɛl ðə fɝst ɹil hoʊp ʃi hæd hæd sɪns ɝaɪvɪŋ ɪn fɑlm. fəɹ ən ɪnstən mɪn faʊn hɝsɛlf ɹiɾɪŋ ði ɔʊɹəz ə ði ʌðɝ tu wɪmən. ðəɹ wɑz deɪnʒɝ, bʌt ðət wɑz tə bi ɪkspɛktəd - ən nu θɪŋz, tu, əmʌŋ ði ɪmədʒəz ʃi hæd sin bɪfɔɹ; ɪt wɑz laɪk ðæt, səmtaɪmz. ə mænz ɹɪŋ ə hɛvi ɡoʊl floʊɾəd əbʌv nɪneɪivz hɛd, ən əbʌv ɪleɪnz, ə ɹɛd-hɑɾ aɪɝn ən ən æks. ðeɪ mɛn tʃɹʌbəl, ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ, bʌɾ ɪt sim dɪstənt, sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ðə fjutʃɝ. oʊnli fəɹ ə moʊmən dɪd ðə ɹɛɾɪŋ læst, ən ðən ɔl ʃi sɔ wɑz ɪleɪn ən nɪneɪiv, wɑtʃɪŋ əɹ ɪkspɛktənli.

Elayne nodded, grinning, and Min felt the first real hope she had had since arriving in Falme. For an instant Min found herself reading the auras of the other two women. There was danger, but that was to be expected - and new things, too, among the images she had seen before; it was like that, sometimes. A man's ring of heavy gold floated above Nynaeve's head, and above Elayne's, a red-hot iron and an axe. They meant trouble, she was sure, but it seemed distant, somewhere in the future. Only for a moment did the reading last, and then all she saw was Elayne and Nynaeve, watching her expectantly.

"ɪts daʊn nɪɹ ðə hɑɹbɝ," ʃi sɛd.

"It's down near the harbor," she said.

ðə sloʊpɪŋ stʃɹit bɪkeɪm mɔɹ kɹaʊɾəd ðə fɝðɝ daʊn ðeɪ wɛnt. stʃɹit pɛdlɝz ɹʌbd ɛlboʊz wɪð mɝtʃəns u hæd bɹɔt wæɡənz ɪn fɹəm ði ɪnlæn vɪlədʒəz ən wəd nɑt ɡoʊ aʊɾ əɡɛn əntɪl wɪntɝ hæd kʌm ən ɡɔn, hɔkɝz wɪð ðɛɹ tʃɹeɪz kɔl tə ðə pæsɝzbi, fɑlmɛn ɪn ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd kloʊks bɹʌʃt pæs fɑɹm fæmliz ɪn hɛvi flis koʊts. mɛni pipəl hæd flɛd hɪɹ fɹəm vɪlədʒəz fɝðɝ fɹəm ðə koʊst. mɪn sɔ noʊ pɔɪn tə ɪt - ðeɪ hæd lɛp fɹəm ðə pɑsəbɪləɾi ʌv ə vɪzət fɹəm ðə sintʃæn tə ðə sɝɾənti ʌv sintʃæn ɔl ɝaʊn əm - bʌt ʃi hæd hɝd wʌt ðə sintʃæn dɪd wən ðeɪ fɝs keɪm tə ə vɪlədʒ, ən ʃi kəd nɑt bleɪm ðə vɪlɪdʒɝz tu mʌtʃ fəɹ fɪɹɪŋ ənʌðɝ əpɪɹəns. ɛvɹiwʌn baʊd wən sintʃæn wɔk pæst əɹ ə kɝteɪn pɑlɑnkwɪn wɑz kæɹid baɪ ʌp ðə stip stʃɹit.

The sloping street became more crowded the further down they went. Street peddlers rubbed elbows with merchants who had brought wagons in from the inland villages and would not go out again until winter had come and gone, hawkers with their trays called to the passersby, Falmen in embroidered cloaks brushed past farm families in heavy fleece coats. Many people had fled here from villages further from the coast. Min saw no point to it - they had leaped from the possibility of a visit from the Seanchan to the certainty of Seanchan all around them - but she had heard what the Seanchan did when they first came to a village, and she could not blame the villagers too much for fearing another appearance. Everyone bowed when Seanchan walked past or a curtained palanquin was carried by up the steep street.

mɪn wɑz ɡlæd tə si nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn nu əbaʊt ðə boʊɪŋ. bɛɹ-tʃɛstəd bɛɹɝz peɪd noʊ mɔɹ maɪn tə ðə pipəl u bɛn ðɛmsɛlvz ðən dɪɾ ɛɹəɡənt, ɑɹmɝd soʊlʒɝz, bʌt feɪljɝ tə baʊ wəd ʃʊɹli kætʃ ðɛɹ aɪz.

Min was glad to see Nynaeve and Elayne knew about the bowing. Bare-chested bearers paid no more mind to the people who bent themselves than did arrogant, armored soldiers, but failure to bow would surely catch their eyes.

ðeɪ tɔkt ə lɪɾəl əz ðeɪ muv daʊn ðə stʃɹit, ən ʃi wɑz sɝpɹaɪzd ət fɝs tə lɝn ðeɪ hæd bɪn ɪn ðə taʊn oʊnli ə fju deɪz lɛs ðən ɛɡwin ən hɝsɛlf. æftɝ ə moʊmənt, ðoʊ, ʃi dɪsaɪɾɪd ɪt wɑz noʊ wʌndɝ ðeɪ hæd nɑt mɛɾ ɝliɝ, nɑt wɪð ðə kɹaʊdz ɪn ðə stʃɹits. ʃi hæd bɪn ɹɪlʌktən tə spɛn taɪm fɝðɝ fɹəm ɛɡwin ðən wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi; ðəɹ wɑz ɔlweɪz ðə fɪɹ ðət ʃi wəd ɡoʊ fəɹ əɹ əlaʊd vɪzəɾ ən faɪn ɛɡwin ɡɔn. ən naʊ ʃɪl bi. ənlɛs nɪneɪiv kən θɪŋk ə sʌmθɪŋ.

They talked a little as they moved down the street, and she was surprised at first to learn they had been in the town only a few days less than Egwene and herself. After a moment, though, she decided it was no wonder they had not met earlier, not with the crowds in the streets. She had been reluctant to spend time further from Egwene than was necessary; there was always the fear that she would go for her allowed visit and find Egwene gone. And now she will be. Unless Nynaeve can think of something.

ðə smɛl ə sɔlt ən pɪtʃ ɡɹu hɛvi ɪn ði ɛɹ, ən ɡʌlz kɹaɪd, wilɪŋ oʊvɝhɛd. seɪlɝz əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə θɹɔŋ, mɛni stɪl bɛɹfʊt dɪspaɪt ðə koʊld.

The smell of salt and pitch grew heavy in the air, and gulls cried, wheeling overhead. Sailors appeared in the throng, many still barefoot despite the cold.

ði ɪn hæd bɪn heɪstəli ɹineɪm ðə θɹi plʌm blɑsəmz, bʌt pɑɹɾ ə ðə wɝd "wɑtʃɝ" stɪl ʃoʊd θɹu ðə slæpdæʃ peɪnt wɝk ɑn ðə saɪn. dɪspaɪt ðə kɹaʊdz aʊtsaɪd, ðə kɑmən ɹum wɑz lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən hæf fʊl; pɹaɪsəz wɝ tu haɪ fəɹ mɛni pipəl tə əfɔɹd taɪm sɪɾɪŋ oʊvɝ eɪl. ɹɔɹɪŋ faɪɝz ɑn hɑɹθs əɾ iðɝ ɛn ə ðə ɹum wɔɹmd ɪt, ən ðə fæɾ ɪnkipɝ wɑz ɪn ɪz ʃɝtslivz. hi aɪd ðə θɹi wɪmən, fɹaʊnɪŋ, ən mɪn θɔɾ ɪt wɑz əɹ sintʃæn dʒɹɛs ðət stɑpt ɪm fɹəm tɛlɪŋ əm tə liv. nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn, ɪn ðɛɹ fɑɹm wɪmənz koʊts, sɝɾənli dɪd nɑt lʊk əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd mʌni tə spɛnd.

The inn had been hastily renamed The Three Plum Blossoms, but part of the word "Watcher" still showed through the slapdash paint work on the sign. Despite the crowds outside, the common room was little more than half full; prices were too high for many people to afford time sitting over ale. Roaring fires on hearths at either end of the room warmed it, and the fat innkeeper was in his shirtsleeves. He eyed the three women, frowning, and Min thought it was her Seanchan dress that stopped him from telling them to leave. Nynaeve and Elayne, in their farm women's coats, certainly did not look as if they had money to spend.

ðə mæn ʃi wɑz lʊkɪŋ fəɹ wɑz əloʊn əɾ ə teɪbəl ɪn ə kɔɹnɝ, ɪn ɪz əkʌstəm pleɪs, mʌɾɝɪŋ ɪndə hɪz waɪn. "du juv taɪm tə tɔk, kæptən doʊmən?" ʃi sɛd.

The man she was looking for was alone at a table in a corner, in his accustomed place, muttering into his wine. "Do you have time to talk, Captain Domon?" she said.

hi lʊkt ʌp, bɹʌʃɪŋ ə hæn əkɹɔs ɪz bɪɹd wən i sɔ ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əloʊn. ʃi stɪl θɔɾ ɪz bɛɹ ʌpɝ lɪp lʊkt ɑd wɪð ðə bɪɹd. "soʊ jə də bɹɪŋ fɹɛnz tə dʒɹɪŋk ʌp maɪ kɔɪn, də ju? wɛl, ðət sintʃæn lɔɹd bɑt maɪ kɑɹɡoʊ, soʊ kɔɪn aɪ hæv. sɪt." ɪleɪn dʒʌmpt əz i sʌɾənli bɛloʊd, "ɪnkipɝ! mʌld waɪn hɪɹ!"

He looked up, brushing a hand across his beard when he saw she was not alone. She still thought his bare upper lip looked odd with the beard. "So you do bring friends to drink up my coin, do you? Well, that Seanchan lord bought my cargo, so coin I have. Sit." Elayne jumped as he suddenly bellowed, "Innkeeper! Mulled wine here!"

"ɪts ɔl ɹaɪt," mɪn toʊl hɝ, teɪkɪŋ ə pleɪs ɑn ði ɛn ʌv wʌn ə ðə bɛntʃɪz ət ðə teɪbəl. "hi oʊnli lʊks ən saʊnz laɪk ə bɛɹ." ɪleɪn sæt daʊn ɑn ði ʌðɝ ɛnd, lʊkɪŋ daʊtfəl.

"It's all right," Min told her, taking a place on the end of one of the benches at the table. "He only looks and sounds like a bear." Elayne sat down on the other end, looking doubtful.

"ə bɛɹ, də aɪ bi?" doʊmən læft. "meɪbi aɪ du. bʌt wʌɾ ə ju, ɡɝl? hæv jə ɡɪvən oʊvɝ θɔɾ ə livɪŋ? ðət dʒɹɛs də lʊk sintʃæn tə mi."

"A bear, do I be?" Domon laughed. "Maybe I do. But what of you, girl? Have you given over thought of leaving? That dress do look Seanchan to me."

"nɛvɝ!" mɪn sɛd fɪɹsli, bʌt ði əpɪɹəns ʌv ə sɝvɪŋ ɡɝl wɪð ðə stimɪŋ, spaɪst waɪn meɪɾ əɹ fɔl saɪlənt.

"Never!" Min said fiercely, but the appearance of a serving girl with the steaming, spiced wine made her fall silent.

doʊmən wɑz dʒʌst əz wɛɹi. hi weɪɾəd əntɪl ðə ɡɝl hæd ɡɔn wɪð ɪz kɔɪnz bɪfɔɹ seɪɪŋ, "fɔɹtʃən pɹɪk mi, ɡɝl, aɪ min noʊ əfɛns. moʊs pipəl oʊnli wɑnə ɡoʊ ɑn wɪð ðɛɹ lɪvz, wɛðɝ ðɛɹ lɔɹdz bi sintʃæn əɹ ɛni ʌðɝ."

Domon was just as wary. He waited until the girl had gone with his coins before saying, "Fortune prick me, girl, I mean no offense. Most people only want to go on with their lives, whether their lords be Seanchan or any other."

nɪneɪiv lin əɹ fɹɑɹmz ɑn ðə teɪbəl. "wi ɔlsoʊ wɑnə ɡoʊ ɑn wɪð əɹ lɪvz, kæptən, bʌt wɪθaʊɾ ɛni sintʃæn. aɪ ʌndɝstæn jə ɪntɛn tə seɪl sun."

Nynaeve leaned her forearms on the table. "We also want to go on with our lives, Captain, but without any Seanchan. I understand you intend to sail soon."

"aɪ wəd seɪl tədeɪ, ɪf aɪ kʊd," doʊmən sɛd ɡlʌmli. "ɛvɹi tu əɹ θɹi deɪz ðət tʃɹɑk də sɛn fəɹ mi tə tɛl ɪm teɪlz ə ði oʊl θɪŋz aɪ hæv sin. də aɪ lʊk ə ɡlimən tə ju? aɪ dɪd θɪŋk aɪ kəd spɪn ə teɪl əɹ tu ən bi ɑn maɪ weɪ, bʌt naʊ aɪ θɪŋk wən aɪ noʊ ɛntɝteɪn ɪm ɛni lɔŋɡɝ, ɪt bi ən ivən weɪdʒɝ wɛðɝ i də lemi ɡoʊ əɹ əv maɪ hɛd kʌɾ ɔf. ðə mæn də lʊk sɑft, bʌɾ i bi əz hɑɹɾ əz aɪɝn, ən əz koʊldhɑɹɾɪd."

"I would sail today, if I could," Domon said glumly. "Every two or three days that Turak do send for me to tell him tales of the old things I have seen. Do I look a gleeman to you? I did think I could spin a tale or two and be on my way, but now I think when I no entertain him any longer, it be an even wager whether he do let me go or have my head cut off. The man do look soft, but he be as hard as iron, and as coldhearted."

"kæn jəɹ ʃɪp əvɔɪd ðə sintʃæn?" nɪneɪiv æskt.

"Can your ship avoid the Seanchan?" Nynaeve asked.

"fɔɹtʃən pɹɪk mi, kəɾ aɪ meɪk ɪɾ aʊɾ ə ðə hɑɹbɝ wɪθaʊɾ ə deɪmeɪn ɹɪps spɹeɪ tə splɪntɝz, aɪ kæn. ɪf aɪ də noʊ lɛɾ ə sintʃæn ʃɪp wɪð ə deɪmeɪn kʌm tu kloʊs wʌns aɪ də meɪk ðə si. ðəɹ bi ʃoʊl wɔɾɝz ɔl əlɔŋ ðɪs koʊst, ən spɹeɪ də hæv ə ʃæloʊ dʒɹæft. aɪ kən teɪk əɹ ɪndə wɔɾɝz ðoʊz lʌmbɝɪŋ sintʃæn hʌlks kən noʊ ɹɪsk. ðeɪ mʌs bi wɛɹi ʌv ðə wɪnz kloʊs ɪnʃɔɹ ðɪs taɪm ə jɪɹ, ən wʌns aɪ də hæv spɹeɪ - "

"Fortune prick me, could I make it out of the harbor without a damane rips Spray to splinters, I can. If I do no let a Seanchan ship with a damane come too close once I do make the sea. There be shoal waters all along this coast, and Spray do have a shallow draft. I can take her into waters those lumbering Seanchan hulks can no risk. They must be wary of the winds close inshore this time of year, and once I do have Spray - "

nɪneɪiv kʌɾ ɪm ɔf. "ðɛn wɪl teɪk pæsədʒ wɪð ju, kæptən. ðəɹ wɪl bi fɔɹ ʌv ʌs, ən əl ɪkspɛk jə tə bi ɹɛɾi tə seɪl əz sun əz wəɹ əbɔɹd."

Nynaeve cut him off. "Then we will take passage with you, Captain. There will be four of us, and I will expect you to be ready to sail as soon as we are aboard."

doʊmən skɹʌbd ə fɪŋɡɝ əkɹɔs ɪz ʌpɝ lɪp ən pɪɹɾ ɪndə hɪz waɪn. "wɛl, əz tə ðæt, ðəɹ stɪl də bi ðə mæɾɝ ʌv ɡɛɾɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə hɑɹbɝ, jə si. ðiz deɪmeɪn - "

Domon scrubbed a finger across his upper lip and peered into his wine. "Well, as to that, there still do be the matter of getting out of the harbor, you see. These damane - "

"wʌɾ ɪf aɪ tɛl jə jəl seɪl wɪð sʌmθɪŋ bɛɾɝ ðən deɪmeɪn?" nɪneɪiv sɛd sɔfli. mɪnz aɪz waɪɾənd əz ʃi ɹilaɪzd wʌt nɪneɪiv ɪntɛndəd.

"What if I tell you you will sail with something better than damane?" Nynaeve said softly. Min's eyes widened as she realized what Nynaeve intended.

ɔlmoʊst ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ, ɪleɪn mɝmɝd, "æn jə tɛl mi tə bi kɛɹfəl."

Almost under her breath, Elayne murmured, "And you tell me to be careful."

doʊmən hæɾ aɪz oʊnli fəɹ nɪneɪiv, ən ðeɪ wɝ wɛɹi aɪz. "wʌt dʒju min?" hi wɪspɝd.

Domon had eyes only for Nynaeve, and they were wary eyes. "What do you mean?" he whispered.

nɪneɪiv oʊpən əɹ koʊt tə fʌmbəl ət ðə bæk ə hɝ nɛk, faɪnəli pʊlɪŋ aʊɾ ə lɛðɝ kɔɹd ðət hæd bɪn tʌkt ɪnsaɪɾ əɹ dʒɹɛs. tu ɡoʊld ɹɪŋz hʌŋ ɑn ðə kɔɹd. mɪn ɡæspt wən ʃi sɔ wʌn - ɪt wɑz ðə hɛvi mænz ɹɪŋ ʃi hæd sin wən ʃi ɹɛd nɪneɪiv ɪn ðə stʃɹit - bʌt ʃi nu ɪt wɑz ði ʌðɝ, slaɪɾɝ ən meɪd fəɹ ə wʊmənz slɛndɝ fɪŋɡɝ, ðət meɪd doʊmənz aɪz bʌlʒ. ə sɝpən baɪɾɪŋ ɪts oʊn teɪl.

Nynaeve opened her coat to fumble at the back of her neck, finally pulling out a leather cord that had been tucked inside her dress. Two gold rings hung on the cord. Min gasped when she saw one - it was the heavy man's ring she had seen when she read Nynaeve in the street - but she knew it was the other, slighter and made for a woman's slender finger, that made Domon's eyes bulge. A serpent biting its own tail.

"ju noʊ wʌt ðɪs minz," nɪneɪiv sɛd, stɑɹɾɪŋ tə slɪp ðə sɝpən ɹɪŋ fɹəm ðə kɔɹd, bʌt doʊmən kloʊzd ɪz hæn oʊvɝ ɪt.

"You know what this means," Nynaeve said, starting to slip the Serpent ring from the cord, but Domon closed his hand over it.

"pʊɾ ɪɾ əweɪ." hɪz aɪz dɑɹɾɪd ənizəli; noʊ wʌn wɑz lʊkɪŋ əɾ əm ðət mɪn kəd si, bʌɾ i lʊkt əz ɪf i θɔɾ ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz stɛɹɪŋ. "ðæt ɹɪŋ də bi deɪnʒɝəs. ɪf ɪt bi sin. . . ."

"Put it away." His eyes darted uneasily; no one was looking at them that Min could see, but he looked as if he thought everyone was staring. "That ring do be dangerous. If it be seen. . . ."

"æz lɔŋ əz jə noʊ wʌɾ ɪt minz," nɪneɪiv sɛd wɪð ə kɑm ðət meɪd mɪn ɛnviəs. ʃi pʊl ðə kɔɹd fɹəm doʊmənz hæn ən ɹɛtaɪɾ ɪɾ ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk.

"As long as you know what it means," Nynaeve said with a calm that made Min envious. She pulled the cord from Domon's hand and retied it around her neck.

"aɪ noʊ," hi sɛd hɔɹsli. "aɪ də noʊ wʌɾ ɪt minz. meɪbi ðəɹ də bi ə tʃæns ɪf ju. . . . fɔɹ, jə seɪ? ðɪs ɡɝl u də laɪk tə lɪsən tə maɪ tʌŋ wæɡ, ʃi də bi wʌn ə ðə fɔɹ, aɪ teɪk ɪt. ən ju, ænd. . . ." hi fɹaʊn əɾ ɪleɪn. "ʃʊɹli ðɪs tʃaɪld ɪz noʊ - noʊ wʌn laɪk ju."

"I know," he said hoarsely. "I do know what it means. Maybe there do be a chance if you. . . . Four, you say? This girl who do like to listen to my tongue wag, she do be one of the four, I take it. And you, and. . . ." He frowned at Elayne. "Surely this child is no - no one like you."

ɪleɪn stʃɹeɪɾənd æŋɡɹəli, bʌt nɪneɪiv pʊɾ ə hæn ɑn əɹ ɑɹm ən smaɪl suðɪŋli ət doʊmən. "ʃi tʃɹævəlz wɪð mi, kæptən. jə maɪt bi sɝpɹaɪz baɪ wʌt wi kən də ivən bɪfɔɹ wi ɝn ðə ɹaɪt tə ə ɹɪŋ. wən wi seɪl, jəl əv θɹi ɑn jəɹ ʃɪp u kən faɪt deɪmeɪn ɪf nid bi."

Elayne straightened angrily, but Nynaeve put a hand on her arm and smiled soothingly at Domon. "She travels with me, Captain. You might be surprised by what we can do even before we earn the right to a ring. When we sail, you will have three on your ship who can fight damane if need be."

"θɹi," hi bɹiðd. "ðɛɹ də bi ə tʃæns. meɪbi. . . ." hɪz feɪs bɹaɪɾənd fəɹ ə moʊmənt, bʌɾ əz i lʊkt ət ðɛm, ɪt ɡɹu sɪɹiəs əɡɛn. "aɪ ʃəd teɪk jə tə spɹeɪ ɹaɪt naʊ ən kæst ɔf, bʌt fɔɹtʃən pɹɪk mi ɪf aɪ kən noʊ tɛl jə wʌt jə feɪs hɪɹ ɪf jə steɪ, ən meɪbi ivən ɪf jə ɡoʊ wɪð mi. lɪsən tə mi, ən mɑɹk wʌɾ aɪ də seɪ." hi tʊk ənʌðɝ kɔʃəs lʊk ɝaʊnd, ən stɪl loʊɝɾ ɪz vɔɪs ən tʃoʊz ɪz wɝdz kɛɹfəli. "aɪ dɪd si ə - ə wʊmən u wɔɹ ə ɹɪŋ laɪk ðət teɪkən baɪ ðə sintʃæn. ə pɹɪɾi, slɛndɝ lɪɾəl wʊmən ʃi wɑz, wɪð ə bɪɡ wɔɹ - ə bɪɡ mæn wɪð əɹ u dɪd lʊk əz ɪf i dɪd noʊ haʊ tə juz ɪz sɔɹd. wʌn ə ðɛm mʌst əv bɪn kɛɹləs, fəɹ ðə sintʃæn dɪɾ əv ən æmbʊʃ leɪd fəɹ ðɛm. ðə bɪɡ mæn pʊt sɪks, sɛvən soʊlʒɝz ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪfɔɹ i dɪd daɪ hɪmsɛlf. ðə - ðə wʊmən. . . . sɪks deɪmeɪn ðeɪ dɪd pʊɾ ɝaʊn hɝ, stɛpɪŋ aʊɾ ə ði æliz ʌv ə sʌɾən. aɪ dɪd θɪŋk ʃi wəd . . . də sʌmθɪŋ - jə noʊ wʌɾ aɪ min - bʌt. . . . aɪ noʊ nʌθɪŋ ə ðiz θɪŋz. wʌn moʊmənt ʃi dɪd lʊk əz ɪf ʃi wəd dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðɛm ɔl, ðən ə lʊk ə hɔɹɝ dɪd kʌm ɑn əɹ feɪs, ən ʃi dɪd skɹim."

"Three," he breathed. "There do be a chance. Maybe. . . ." His face brightened for a moment, but as he looked at them, it grew serious again. "I should take you to Spray right now and cast off, but Fortune prick me if I can no tell you what you face here if you stay, and maybe even if you go with me. Listen to me, and mark what I do say." He took another cautious look around, and still lowered his voice and chose his words carefully. "I did see a - a woman who wore a ring like that taken by the Seanchan. A pretty, slender little woman she was, with a big War - a big man with her who did look as if he did know how to use his sword. One of them must have been careless, for the Seanchan did have an ambush laid for them. The big man put six, seven soldiers on the ground before he did die himself. The - the woman. . . . Six damane they did put around her, stepping out of the alleys of a sudden. I did think she would . . . do something - you know what I mean - but. . . . I know nothing of these things. One moment she did look as if she would destroy them all, then a look of horror did come on her face, and she did scream."

"ðeɪ kʌɾ əɹ ɔf fɹəm ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs." ɪleɪnz feɪs wɑz waɪt.

"They cut her off from the True Source." Elayne's face was white.

"noʊ mæɾɝ," nɪneɪiv sɛd kɑmli. "wi wɪl nɑɾ əlaʊ ðə seɪm tə bi dʌn tə ʌs."

"No matter," Nynaeve said calmly. "We will not allow the same to be done to us."

"aɪ, meɪæp ɪɾəl bi əz jə seɪ. bʌɾ əl ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɪɾ əntɪl aɪ daɪ. ɹaɪmə, hɛlp mi. ðəɾ ɪz wʌt ʃi dɪd skɹim. ən wʌn ə ðə deɪmeɪn dɪd fɔl daʊn kɹaɪɪŋ, ən ðeɪ dɪd pʊt wʌn ə ðoʊz kɑlɝz ɑn ðə nɛk ə ðə . . . wʊmən, ən aɪ . . . aɪ dɪd ɹʌn." hi ʃɹʌɡd, ən ɹʌbd ɪz noʊz, ən pɪɹɾ ɪndə hɪz waɪn. "aɪ hæv sin θɹi wɪmən teɪkən, ən aɪ hæv noʊ stʌmək fəɹ ɪt. aɪ wəd liv maɪ eɪdʒd ɡɹændmʌðɝ stændɪŋ ɑn ðə dɑk tə seɪl fɹəm hɪɹ, bʌɾ aɪ dɪɾ əv tə tɛl ju."

"Aye, mayhap it will be as you say. But I will remember it until I die. Ryma, help me. That is what she did scream. And one of the damane did fall down crying, and they did put one of those collars on the neck of the . . . woman, and I . . . I did run." He shrugged, and rubbed his nose, and peered into his wine. "I have seen three women taken, and I have no stomach for it. I would leave my aged grandmother standing on the dock to sail from here, but I did have to tell you."

"ɛɡwin sɛd ðeɪv tu pɹɪznɝz," mɪn sɛd sloʊli. "ɹaɪmə, ə jɛloʊ, ən ʃi dɪdnt noʊ hu ði ʌðɝ ɪz." nɪneɪiv ɡeɪv əɹ ə ʃɑɹp lʊk, ən ʃi fɛl saɪlənt, blʌʃɪŋ. fɹəm ðə lʊk ɑn doʊmənz feɪs, ɪt hæd nɑt fɝðɝd ðɛɹ kɑz ɛni tə tɛl ɪm ðə sintʃæn hɛl tu ɛɛs sədaɪ, nɑt dʒʌst wʌn.

"Egwene said they have two prisoners," Min said slowly. "Ryma, a Yellow, and she didn't know who the other is." Nynaeve gave her a sharp look, and she fell silent, blushing. From the look on Domon's face, it had not furthered their cause any to tell him the Seanchan held two Aes Sedai, not just one.

jɛɾ əbɹʌpli hi stɛɹɾ ət nɪneɪiv ən tʊk ə lɔŋ ɡʌlp ʌv waɪn. "du ðət bi waɪ jə ɑɹ hɪɹ? tə fɹi . . . ðoʊz tu? jə dɪd seɪ ðəɹ wəd bi θɹi ʌv ju."

Yet abruptly he stared at Nynaeve and took a long gulp of wine. "Do that be why you are here? To free . . . those two? You did say there would be three of you."

"ju noʊ wʌt jə nid tə noʊ," nɪneɪiv toʊld ɪm bɹɪskli. "ju mʌs bi ɹɛɾi tə seɪl ɑn ði ɪnstən ɛnitaɪm ɪn ðə nɛks tu əɹ θɹi deɪz. wɪl jə də ɪt, əɹ wɪl jə ɹɪmeɪn hɪɹ tə si ɪf ðəl kʌɾ ɔf jəɹ hɛɾ æftɝ ɔl? ðəɹ ɑɹ ʌðɝ ʃɪps, kæptən, ən aɪ min tə hæv pæsədʒ əʃʊɹɾ ɑn wʌn ə ðɛm tədeɪ."

"You know what you need to know," Nynaeve told him briskly. "You must be ready to sail on the instant anytime in the next two or three days. Will you do it, or will you remain here to see if they will cut off your head after all? There are other ships, Captain, and I mean to have passage assured on one of them today."

mɪn hɛld əɹ bɹɛθ; ʌndɝ ðə teɪbəl, hɝ fɪŋɡɝz wɝ nɑɾɪd.

Min held her breath; under the table, her fingers were knotted.

faɪnəli, doʊmən nɑɾəd. "aɪ wɪl bi ɹɛɾi."

Finally, Domon nodded. "I will be ready."

wən ðeɪ ɹɪtɝn tə ðə stʃɹit, mɪn wɑz sɝpɹaɪz tə si nɪneɪiv sæɡ əɡɛns ðə fɹʌn ə ði ɪn əz sun əz ðə dɔɹ kloʊzd. "ɑɹ jə ɪl, nɪneɪiv?" ʃi æskt æŋkʃəsli.

When they returned to the street, Min was surprised to see Nynaeve sag against the front of the inn as soon as the door closed. "Are you ill, Nynaeve?" she asked anxiously.

nɪneɪiv dʒɹu ə lɔŋ bɹɛθ ən stʊɾ ʌp stʃɹeɪt, tʌɡɪŋ əɾ əɹ koʊt. "wɪð səm pipəl," ʃi sɛd, "ju hæv tə bi sɝɾən. ɪf jə ʃoʊ ðɛm wʌn ɡlɪmɝ ə daʊt, ðəl swip jə ɔf ɪn səm dɝɛkʃən jə doʊnt wɑnə ɡoʊ. laɪt, bʌɾ aɪ wɑz əfɹeɪɾ i wɑz gɑnə seɪ noʊ. kʌm, wɪv plænz jɛt tə meɪk. ðəɹ ɑɹ stɪl wʌn əɹ tu smɔl pɹɑbləmz tə wɝk aʊt."

Nynaeve drew a long breath and stood up straight, tugging at her coat. "With some people," she said, "you have to be certain. If you show them one glimmer of doubt, they'll sweep you off in some direction you don't want to go. Light, but I was afraid he was going to say no. Come, we have plans yet to make. There are still one or two small problems to work out."

"aɪ hoʊp jə doʊn maɪn fɪʃ, mɪn," ɪleɪn sɛd.

"I hope you don't mind fish, Min," Elayne said.

wʌn əɹ tu smɔl pɹɑbləmz? mɪn θɔɾ əz ʃi fɑloʊd ðɛm. ʃi hoʊp vɛɹi mʌtʃ ðət nɪneɪiv wɑz nɑt dʒʌs biɪŋ sɝɾən əɡɛn.

One or two small problems? Min thought as she followed them. She hoped very much that Nynaeve was not just being certain again.


tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾifɔɹ


CHAPTER 44

faɪv wɪl ɹaɪd fɔɹθ


Five Will Ride Forth

pɛɹɪn aɪd ðə vɪlɪdʒɝz wɛɹəli, sɛlf-kɑnʃəsli hɪtʃɪŋ əɾ ə tu-ʃɔɹt kloʊk, ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɑn ðə tʃɛst ən wɪð səm hoʊlz ɪn ɪt nɑɾ ivən pætʃt, bʌt nʌn ə ðɛm ɡeɪv ɪm ə sɛkənd ɡlæns dɪspaɪɾ ɪz stʃɹeɪnʒ mɪks ə kloʊðz ən ði æks ɑn ɪz hɪp. hʊɹɪn hæɾ ə koʊt wɪð blu spaɪɹəlz əkɹɔs ðə tʃɛst ʌndɝ ɪz kloʊk, ən mæt wɔɹ ə pɛɹ ə bæɡi tʃɹaʊzɝz ðət meɪd bʌntʃəz wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ stʌft ɪndə hɪz buts. ðət hæd bɪn ɔl ðeɪ hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə faɪn ðət wəd fɪt bæk ɪn ði əbændən vɪlədʒ. pɛɹɪn wʌndɝɾ ɪf ðɪs wʌn wəd bi əbændən sun. hæf ðə stoʊn haʊsəz wɝ ɛmpti, ən ɪn fɹʌn ə ði ɪn, ʌp ðə dɝt stʃɹit fɹəm ðɛm, θɹi ɑks kɑɹts, loʊɾəd tu hɛvəli ɪn ɡɹeɪt maʊnz ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ kʌvɝd wɪð ɹoʊp kænvəs, stʊd wɪð fæmliz ɡæðɝɾ ɝaʊn ðɛm.

Perrin eyed the villagers warily, self-consciously hitching at a too-short cloak, embroidered on the chest and with some holes in it not even patched, but none of them gave him a second glance despite his strange mix of clothes and the axe on his hip. Hurin had a coat with blue spirals across the chest under his cloak, and Mat wore a pair of baggy trousers that made bunches where they were stuffed into his boots. That had been all they had been able to find that would fit back in the abandoned village. Perrin wondered if this one would be abandoned soon. Half the stone houses were empty, and in front of the inn, up the dirt street from them, three ox carts, loaded too heavily in great mounds and everything covered with roped canvas, stood with families gathered around them.

əz i wɑtʃt ðɛm, hʌɾəlɪŋ təɡɛðɝ ən seɪɪŋ ðɛɹ ɡʊdbaɪz tə ðoʊz u wɝ steɪɪŋ, ət lis fəɹ ðə taɪm biɪŋ, pɛɹɪn dɪsaɪɾɪd ɪt wɑz nɑt læk ʌv ɪntʃɹəst ɪn stʃɹeɪnʒɝz ɑn ðə vɪlɪdʒɝz' pɑɹt; ðeɪ wɝ kɛɹfəli əvɔɪɾɪŋ lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪm ən ði ʌðɝz. ðiz pipəl hæd lɝnd nɑt tə ʃoʊ kjʊɹiɑsəɾi əbaʊt stʃɹeɪnʒɝz, ivən stʃɹeɪnʒɝz u wɝ ɑbviəsli nɑt sintʃæn. stʃɹeɪnʒɝz maɪt bi deɪnʒɝəs ðiz deɪz ɑn toʊmən hɛd. ðeɪ hæɾ ɪnkaʊntɝd ðə seɪm stuɾiəs ɪndɪfɝəns ɪn ʌðɝ vɪlədʒəz. ðəɹ wɝ mɔɹ taʊnz hɪɹ wɪðɪn ə fju liɡz ə ðə koʊst, ɛvɹi wʌn hoʊldɪŋ ɪtsɛlf ɪndɪpɛndənt. əɾ ɛni ɹeɪt, ðeɪ hæɾ əntɪl ðə sintʃæn keɪm.

As he watched them, huddling together and saying their goodbyes to those who were staying, at least for the time being, Perrin decided it was not lack of interest in strangers on the villagers' part; they were carefully avoiding looking at him and the others. These people had learned not to show curiosity about strangers, even strangers who were obviously not Seanchan. Strangers might be dangerous these days on Toman Head. They had encountered the same studious indifference in other villages. There were more towns here within a few leagues of the coast, every one holding itself independent. At any rate, they had until the Seanchan came.

"aɪ seɪ ɪts taɪm tə ɡoʊ ɡɛt ðə hɔɹsəz," mæt sɛd, "bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ dɪsaɪd tə stɑɹɾ æskɪŋ kwɛstʃənz. ðəɹ əz tə bi ə fɝs taɪm fəɹ ɪt."

"I say it's time to go get the horses," Mat said, "before they decide to start asking questions. There has to be a first time for it."

hʊɹɪn wɑz stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ə bɪɡ, blækən sɝkəl ʌv ɡɹaʊn ðət mɑɹd ðə bɹaʊn ɡɹæs ə ðə vɪlədʒ ɡɹin. ɪt hæɾ ə wɛðɝd lʊk, bʌt noʊ wʌn hæd dʌn ɛniθɪŋ tə ɪɹeɪs ɪt. "meɪbi sɪks əɹ eɪt mʌnθs əɡoʊ," hi mʌɾɝd, "æn ɪt stɪl stɪŋks. ðə hoʊl vɪlədʒ kaʊnsəl ən ðɛɹ fæmliz. waɪ wəd ðeɪ də ə θɪŋ laɪk ðæt?"

Hurin was staring at a big, blackened circle of ground that marred the brown grass of the village green. It had a weathered look, but no one had done anything to erase it. "Maybe six or eight months ago," he muttered, "and it still stinks. The whole Village Council and their families. Why would they do a thing like that?"

"hu noʊz waɪ ðeɪ də ɛniθɪŋ?" mæt mʌɾɝd. "sintʃæn doʊn sim tə niɾ ə ɹizən fəɹ kɪlɪŋ pipəl. nʌn aɪ kən fɪɡjɝ aʊt, ɛniweɪ."

"Who knows why they do anything?" Mat muttered. "Seanchan don't seem to need a reason for killing people. None I can figure out, anyway."

pɛɹɪn tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə lʊk ət ðə tʃɑɹd pætʃ. "hʊɹɪn, ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ əbaʊt feɪn? hʊɹɪn?" ɪt hæd bɪn hɑɹd tə meɪk ðə snɪfɝ lʊk əɾ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls sɪns ðeɪ ɛntɝd ðə vɪlədʒ. "hʊɹɪn!"

Perrin tried not to look at the charred patch. "Hurin, are you sure about Fain? Hurin?" It had been hard to make the sniffer look at anything else since they entered the village. "Hurin!"

"wʌt? oʊ. feɪn. jɛs." hʊɹɪnz nɑstʃɹəlz flɛɹd, ən ɹaɪɾ əweɪ hi ɹɪŋkəld ɪz noʊz. "ðɛɹz noʊ mɪsteɪkɪŋ ðæt, ivən oʊld əz ɪɾ ɪz. meɪks ə mɹdʒɹɑl smɛl laɪk ɹoʊzɪz. hi pæs θɹu hɪɹ ɔl ɹaɪt, bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk i wɑz əloʊn. noʊ tʃɹɑləks, ɛniweɪ, ən ɪf i hæɾ ɛni dɑɹkfɹɛnz wɪð hɪm, ðeɪ hædn bɪn ʌp tə mʌtʃ leɪtli."

"What? Oh. Fain. Yes." Hurin's nostrils flared, and right away he wrinkled his nose. "There's no mistaking that, even old as it is. Makes a Myrddraal smell like roses. He passed through here all right, but I think he was alone. No Trollocs, anyway, and if he had any Darkfriends with him, they hadn't been up to much lately."

ðəɹ wɑz səm sɔɹɾ ʌv ædʒəteɪʃən ʌp baɪ ði ɪn, pipəl ʃaʊɾɪŋ ən pɔɪntɪŋ. nɑɾ ət pɛɹɪn ən ði ʌðɝ tu, bʌɾ ət sʌmθɪŋ pɛɹɪn kəd nɑt si ɪn ðə loʊ hɪlz ist ə ðə vɪlədʒ.

There was some sort of agitation up by the inn, people shouting and pointing. Not at Perrin and the other two, but at something Perrin could not see in the low hills east of the village.

"kæn wi ɡɛt ðə hɔɹsəz naʊ?" mæt sɛd. "ðæt kəd bi sintʃæn."

"Can we get the horses now?" Mat said. "That could be Seanchan."

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd, ən ðeɪ bɹoʊk ɪndə ə ɹʌn fəɹ wɛɹ ðeɪ hæd taɪd ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz bɪhaɪn ən əbændən haʊs. əz mæt ən hʊɹɪn dɪsəpɪɹɾ ɝaʊn ðə kɔɹnɝ ə ðə haʊs, pɛɹɪn lʊk bæk təwɔɹd ði ɪn ən stɑpt ɪn əstɑnɪʃmənt. ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt wɝ ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪndə taʊn, ə lɔŋ kɑləm ə ðɛm.

Perrin nodded, and they broke into a run for where they had tied their horses behind an abandoned house. As Mat and Hurin disappeared around the corner of the house, Perrin looked back toward the inn and stopped in astonishment. The Children of the Light were riding into town, a long column of them.

hi lɛpt æftɝ ði ʌðɝz. "waɪtkloʊks!"

He leaped after the others. "Whitecloaks!"

ðeɪ weɪstəɾ oʊnli ən ɪnstən stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪm ɪn dɪsbɪlif bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ wɝ skɹæmbəlɪŋ ɪndə ðɛɹ sæɾəlz. kipɪŋ haʊsəz bɪtwin əm ən ðə meɪn stʃɹiɾ ə ðə vɪlədʒ, ðə θɹi ɡæləpt aʊɾ ə ðə vɪlədʒ wɛstwɝd, wɑtʃɪŋ oʊvɝ ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz fəɹ pɝsut. ɪŋtʃɹ hæd toʊld əm tə əvɔɪɾ ɛniθɪŋ ðət maɪt sloʊ ðɛm daʊn, ən waɪtkloʊks æskɪŋ kwɛstʃənz wəd sɝɾənli də ðæt, ivən ɪf ðeɪ kəd mænədʒ ænsɝz ðət sæɾəsfaɪd. pɛɹɪn kɛpt ən ivən kloʊsɝ wɑtʃ ðən ði ʌðɝ tu; hi hæɾ ɪz oʊn ɹizənz fəɹ nɑt wɑntɪŋ tə mit waɪtkloʊks. ði æks ɪn maɪ hænz. laɪt, wʌɾ aɪ wʊdnt ɡɪv tə tʃeɪnʒ ðæt.

They wasted only an instant staring at him in disbelief before they were scrambling into their saddles. Keeping houses between them and the main street of the village, the three galloped out of the village westward, watching over their shoulders for pursuit. Ingtar had told them to avoid anything that might slow them down, and Whitecloaks asking questions would certainly do that, even if they could manage answers that satisfied. Perrin kept an even closer watch than the other two; he had his own reasons for not wanting to meet Whitecloaks. The axe in my hands. Light, what I wouldn't give to change that.

ðə laɪtli wʊɾɪd hɪlz sun hɪd ðə vɪlədʒ, ən pɛɹɪn bɪɡæn tə θɪŋk meɪbi ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tʃeɪsɪŋ əm æftɝ ɔl. hi ɹeɪn ɪn ən moʊʃən ði ʌðɝ tu tə stɑp. wən ðeɪ dɪd, aɪɪŋ ɪm kwɛstʃənɪŋli, hi lɪsənd. hɪz ɪɹz wɝ ʃɑɹpɝ ðən ðeɪ wʌns hæd bɪn, bʌɾ i hɝd noʊ saʊnz ə hʊfbits.

The lightly wooded hills soon hid the village, and Perrin began to think maybe there was nothing chasing them after all. He reined in and motioned the other two to stop. When they did, eyeing him questioningly, he listened. His ears were sharper than they once had been, but he heard no sounds of hoofbeats.

ɹɪlʌktənli, hi ɹitʃt aʊt wɪð ɪz maɪn ɪn sɝtʃ ʌv wʊlvz. ɔlmoʊst ɪmiɾiətli hi faʊn ðɛm, ə smɔl pæk laɪɪŋ ʌp fəɹ ðə deɪ ɪn ðə hɪlz əbʌv ðə vɪlədʒ ðeɪ hæd dʒʌs lɛft. ðəɹ wɝ moʊməns ʌv əstɑnɪʃmən soʊ stʃɹɔŋ i ɔlmoʊs θɔɾ ɪt wɑz ɪz oʊn; ðiz wʊlvz hæd hɝd ɹumɝz, bʌt ðeɪ hæd nɑt ɹɪli bɪliv ðəɹ wɝ tu-lɛɡz u kəd tɔk tə ðɛɹ kaɪnd. hi swɛɾɪd θɹu ðə mɪnəts ɪt tʊk tə ɡɛt pæst ɪntʃɹədusɪŋ hɪmsɛlf - hi ɡeɪv ði ɪmədʒ ə jʌŋ bʊl ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɪmsɛlf, ən æɾəd ɪz oʊn smɛl, əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ðə kʌstəm əmʌŋ wʊlvz; wʊlvz wɝ ɡɹeɪt wʌnz fəɹ fɔɹmæləɾiz ɑn fɝs miɾɪŋz - bʌt faɪnəli hi mænədʒ tə ɡɛɾ ɪz kwɛstʃən θɹu. ðeɪ ɹɪli hæd noʊ ɪntʃɹəst ɪn ɛni tu-lɛɡz u kəd nɑt tɔk tə ðɛm, bʌɾ ət læs ðeɪ ɡlaɪɾɪd daʊn tə teɪk ə lʊk, ənsin baɪ ðə dʌl aɪz ə ðə tu-lɛɡz.

Reluctantly, he reached out with his mind in search of wolves. Almost immediately he found them, a small pack lying up for the day in the hills above the village they had just left. There were moments of astonishment so strong he almost thought it was his own; these wolves had heard rumors, but they had not really believed there were two-legs who could talk to their kind. He sweated through the minutes it took to get past introducing himself - he gave the image of Young Bull in spite of himself, and added his own smell, according to the custom among wolves; wolves were great ones for formalities on first meetings - but finally he managed to get his question through. They really had no interest in any two-legs who could not talk to them, but at last they glided down to take a look, unseen by the dull eyes of the two-legs.

æftɝ ə taɪm, ɪmədʒəz keɪm bæk tə hɪm, wʌt ðə wʊlvz sɔ. waɪt-kloʊk mɛn ɑn hɔɹsəz kɹaʊɾɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə vɪlədʒ, ɹaɪɾɪŋ əmʌŋ ðə haʊsəz, ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɝaʊn ɪt, bʌt nʌn livɪŋ. ɪspɛʃli nɑt wɛstwɝd. ðə wʊlvz sɛɾ ɔl ðeɪ smɛl muvɪŋ wɛst wɑz hɪmsɛlf ən tu ʌðɝ tu-lɛɡz wɪð θɹi ʌv ðə hɑɹd-fʊɾɪd tɔl wʌnz.

After a time, images came back to him, what the wolves saw. White-cloaked men on horses crowding around the village, riding among the houses, riding around it, but none leaving. Especially not westward. The wolves said all they smelled moving west was himself and two other two-legs with three of the hard-footed tall ones.

pɛɹɪn lɛt ɡoʊ ðə kɑntækt wɪð ðə wʊlvz ɡɹeɪtfəli. hi wɑz əwɛɹ ə hʊɹɪn ən mæt lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm.

Perrin let go the contact with the wolves gratefully. He was aware of Hurin and Mat looking at him.

"ðeɪ ɑɹən fɑloʊɪŋ," hi sɛd.

"They aren't following," he said.

"haʊ kən jə bi ʃʊɹ?" mæt dɪmændəd.

"How can you be sure?" Mat demanded.

"aɪ æm!" hi snæpt, ðən mɔɹ sɔfli, "aɪ dʒʌst æm."

"I am!" he snapped, then more softly, "I just am."

mæt oʊpən ɪz maʊθ ən kloʊzd ɪɾ əɡɛn, ən faɪnəli sɛd, "wɛl, ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹən kʌmɪŋ æftɝ ʌs, aɪ seɪ wi ɡoʊ bæk tə ɪŋtʃɹ ən ɡɛɾ ɑn feɪnz tʃɹeɪl. ðət dæɡɝ ɪzən kʌmɪŋ ɛni kloʊsɝ dʒʌst stændɪŋ hɪɹ."

Mat opened his mouth and closed it again, and finally said, "Well, if they aren't coming after us, I say we go back to Ingtar and get on Fain's trail. That dagger isn't coming any closer just standing here."

"wi kæn pɪk ɪɾ ʌp əɡɛn ðɪs kloʊs tə ðət vɪlədʒ," hʊɹɪn sɛd. "nɑt wɪθaʊt ɹɪskɪŋ ɹʌnɪŋ ɪndə waɪtkloʊks. aɪ doʊn θɪŋk lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹ wəɾ əpɹiʃieɪt ðæt, ən nɑt vɛɹɪn sədaɪ, niðɝ."

"We can't pick it up again this close to that village," Hurin said. "Not without risking running into Whitecloaks. I don't think Lord Ingtar would appreciate that, and not Verin Sedai, neither."

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd. "wil fɑloʊ ɪɾ ɑn ə fju maɪlz, ɛniweɪ. bʌt kip ə kloʊs lʊkaʊt. wi kæn bi tu fɑɹ fɹəm fɑlm, naʊ. ɪt woʊn də ɛni ɡʊd tə əvɔɪd ðə waɪtkloʊks ən ɹaɪd ɹaɪɾ ɪndə ə sintʃæn pətʃɹoʊl."

Perrin nodded. "We'll follow it on a few miles, anyway. But keep a close lookout. We can't be too far from Falme, now. It won't do any good to avoid the Whitecloaks and ride right into a Seanchan patrol."

əz ðeɪ stɑɹɾəd aʊɾ əɡɛn, hi kəd nɑt hɛlp wʌndɝɪŋ wʌt waɪtkloʊks wɝ duɪŋ ðɛɹ.

As they started out again, he could not help wondering what Whitecloaks were doing there.
