dʒɛəfɹæm bɔɹnhəl pɪɹd daʊn ðə vɪlədʒ stʃɹit, sɪɾɪŋ ɪz sæɾəl waɪl ðə lidʒən spɹɛd θɹu ðə smɔl taʊn ən sɝaʊndəɾ ɪt. ðəɹ hæd bɪn sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ðə hɛvi-ʃoʊldɝd mæn u hæd dæʃt aʊɾ ə saɪt, sʌmθɪŋ ðət tɪkəld ɪz mɛmɹi. jɛs, ʌv kɔɹs. ðə læɾ u kleɪm tə bi ə blæksmɪθ. wʌt wɑz ɪz neɪm?

Geofram Bornhald peered down the village street, sitting his saddle while the legion spread through the small town and surrounded it. There had been something about the heavy-shouldered man who had dashed out of sight, something that tickled his memory. Yes, of course. The lad who claimed to be a blacksmith. What was his name?

baɪɑɝ pʊld ʌp ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm, hæn ɑn hɑɹt. "ðə vɪlədʒ ɪz sɪkjʊɹd, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən."

Byar pulled up in front of him, hand on heart. "The village is secured, my Lord Captain."

vɪlɪdʒɝz ɪn hɛvi ʃipskɪn koʊts mɪld ənizəli əz waɪt-kloʊk soʊlʒɝz hɝɾɪd əm təɡɛðɝ nɪɹ ði oʊvɝloʊɾɪd kɑɹts ɪn fɹʌn ə ði ɪn. kɹaɪɪŋ tʃɪlʒɹən klʌŋ tə ðɛɹ mʌðɝz' skɝts, bʌt noʊ wʌn lʊk dɪfaɪənt. dʌl aɪz stɛɹɾ aʊɾ ə ði ədʌl feɪsəz, weɪɾɪŋ pæsɪvli fəɹ wʌtɛvɝ wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə hæpən. fəɹ ðət mʌtʃ, bɔɹnhəld wɑz ɡɹeɪtfəl. hi hæd noʊ ɹil dɪzaɪɝ tə meɪk ən ɪɡzæmpəl ʌv ɛni ʌv ðiz pipəl, ən noʊ wɪʃ əɾ ɔl tə weɪs taɪm.

Villagers in heavy sheepskin coats milled uneasily as white-cloaked soldiers herded them together near the overloaded carts in front of the inn. Crying children clung to their mothers' skirts, but no one looked defiant. Dull eyes stared out of the adult faces, waiting passively for whatever was going to happen. For that much, Bornhald was grateful. He had no real desire to make an example of any of these people, and no wish at all to waste time.

dɪsmaʊntɪŋ, hi tɔst ɪz ɹeɪnz tə wʌn ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən. "si ðət ðə mɛn ɑɹ fɛd, baɪɑɝ. pʊt ðə pɹɪznɝz ɪn ði ɪn wɪð əz mʌtʃ fuɾ ən wɔɾɝ əz ðeɪ kən kæɹi, ðən neɪl ɔl ðə dɔɹz ən ʃʌɾɝz kloʊzd. meɪk əm θɪŋk aɪm livɪŋ səm mɛn tə stænd ɡɑɹd, jɛs?"

Dismounting, he tossed his reins to one of the Children. "See that the men are fed, Byar. Put the prisoners in the inn with as much food and water as they can carry, then nail all the doors and shutters closed. Make them think I am leaving some men to stand guard, yes?"

baɪɑɝ tʌtʃt ɪz hɑɹɾ əɡɛn ən wild ɪz hɔɹs tə ʃaʊɾ ɔɹɾɝz. ðə hɝɾɪŋ bɪɡæn ənu, ɪndə ðə flæt-ɹuft ɪn, waɪl ʌðɝ tʃɪlʒɹən ɹænsæk haʊsəz sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ hæmɝz ən neɪlz.

Byar touched his heart again and wheeled his horse to shout orders. The herding began anew, into the flat-roofed inn, while other Children ransacked houses searching for hammers and nails.

wɑtʃɪŋ ðə sʌlən feɪsəz ðət faɪl pæs hɪm, bɔɹnhəl θɔɾ ɪt ʃəd bi tu əɹ θɹi deɪz bɪfɔɹ ɛni ʌv əm faʊn ɪnʌf kɝədʒ tə bɹeɪk aʊɾ ə ði ɪn ən faɪn ðəɹ wɝ noʊ ɡɑɹdz. tu əɹ θɹi deɪz wɑz ɔl i niɾəd, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑɾ ɪntɛn tə ɹɪsk əlɝɾɪŋ ðə sintʃæn tə hɪz pɹɛzəns naʊ.

Watching the sullen faces that filed past him, Bornhald thought it should be two or three days before any of them found enough courage to break out of the inn and find there were no guards. Two or three days was all he needed, but he did not intend to risk alerting the Seanchan to his presence now.

livɪŋ ɪnʌf mɛn bɪhaɪn tə meɪk ðə kwɛstʃənɝz bɪliv ɪz ɪntaɪɝ lidʒən wɑz stɪl skæɾɝd əkɹɔs ɑlməθ pleɪn, hi hæd bɹɔt mɔɹ ðən ə θaʊzən ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən nɪɹli ðə lɛŋθ ə toʊmən hɛd wɪθaʊt ɡɪvɪŋ əlɑɹm, soʊ fɑɹ əz i nu. θɹi skɝmɪʃɪz wɪð sintʃæn pətʃɹoʊlz hæɾ ɛndəd kwɪkli. ðə sintʃæn hæd ɡɹoʊn juz tə feɪsɪŋ ɔlɹɛɾi dɪfiɾəd ɹæbəl; ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt hæd bɪn ə dɛdli sɝpɹaɪz. jɛt ðə sintʃæn nu haʊ tə faɪt laɪk ðə dɑɹk wʌnz hɔɹdz, ən i kəd nɑt hɛlp ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ðə wʌn skɝmɪʃ ðət hæd kɑst ɪm bɛɾɝ ðən fɪfti mɛn. hi wɑz stɪl nɑt ʃʊɹ wɪtʃ ə ðə tu æɹoʊ-ɹɪɾəld wɪmən i hæd stɛɹɾ əɾ æftɝwɝdz hæd bɪn ði ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Leaving enough men behind to make the Questioners believe his entire legion was still scattered across Almoth Plain, he had brought more than a thousand of the Children nearly the length of Toman Head without giving alarm, so far as he knew. Three skirmishes with Seanchan patrols had ended quickly. The Seanchan had grown used to facing already defeated rabble; the Children of the Light had been a deadly surprise. Yet the Seanchan knew how to fight like the Dark One's hordes, and he could not help remembering the one skirmish that had cost him better than fifty men. He was still not sure which of the two arrow-riddled women he had stared at afterwards had been the Aes Sedai.

"baɪɑɝ!" wʌn ə bɔɹnhəlz mɛn hændəɾ ɪm wɔɾɝ ɪn ə pɑɾɝi kʌp fɹəm wʌn ə ðə kɑɹts; ɪt wɑz aɪsi ɪn ɪz θɹoʊt.

"Byar!" One of Bornhald's men handed him water in a pottery cup from one of the carts; it was icy in his throat.

ðə ɡɔnt-feɪs mæn swʌŋ daʊn fɹəm ɪz sæɾəl. "jɛs, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən?"

The gaunt-faced man swung down from his saddle. "Yes, my Lord Captain?"

"wɛn aɪ ɛnɡeɪdʒ ði ɛnəmi, baɪɑɝ," bɔɹnhəl sɛd sloʊli, "ju wɪl nɑt teɪk pɑɹt. jəl wɑtʃ fɹəm ə dɪstəns, ən jəl kæɹi wɝd tə maɪ sʌn ʌv wʌt hæpənz."

"When I engage the enemy, Byar," Bornhald said slowly, "you will not take part. You will watch from a distance, and you will carry word to my son of what happens."

"bʌt maɪ lɔɹd kæptən - !"

"But my Lord Captain - !"

"ðæɾ ɪz maɪ ɔɹɾɝ, tʃaɪl baɪɑɝ!" hi snæpt. "ju wɪl oʊbeɪ, jɛs?"

"That is my order, Child Byar!" he snapped. "You will obey, yes?"

baɪɑɝz bæk stɪfənd, ən i stɛɹd stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛd. "æz jə kəmænd, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən."

Byar's back stiffened, and he stared straight ahead. "As you command, my Lord Captain."

bɔɹnhəl stʌɾid ɪm fəɹ ə moʊmənt. ðə mæn wəd də əz i wɑz toʊld, bʌɾ ɪt wəd bi bɛɾɝ tə ɡɪv ɪm ənʌðɝ ɹizən ðən lɛɾɪŋ deɪn noʊ haʊ hɪz fɑðɝ hæd daɪd. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ əz ɪf i dɪd nɑɾ əv nɑlədʒ ðət wɑz ɝdʒənli niɾəd ɪn æmədɔɹ. sɪns ðət skɝmɪʃ wɪð ði ɛɛs sədaɪ - wɑz ɪt wʌn ə ðɛm, əɹ boʊθ? θɝɾi sintʃæn soʊlʒɝz, ɡʊd faɪɾɝz, ən tu wɪmən kɑs mi twaɪs ðə kæʒəwəltiz ðeɪ dɪd. - sɪns ðɛn, hi noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɪkspɛktəd tə lɪv tə liv toʊmən hɛd. ɪn ðə smɔl tʃæns ðə sintʃæn dɪd nɑt si tə ɪt, vɛɹi laɪkli ðə kwɛstʃənɝz wʊd.

Bornhald studied him for a moment. The man would do as he was told, but it would be better to give him another reason than letting Dain know how his father had died. It was not as if he did not have knowledge that was urgently needed in Amador. Since that skirmish with the Aes Sedai - Was it one of them, or both? Thirty Seanchan soldiers, good fighters, and two women cost me twice the casualties they did. - since then, he no longer expected to live to leave Toman Head. In the small chance the Seanchan did not see to it, very likely the Questioners would.

"wɛn juv faʊn maɪ sʌn - hi ʃəd bi wɪð lɔɹd kæptən imən vɑldə nɪɹ tɑɹ vəlɑn - ən toʊl hɪm, jəl ɹaɪd tə æmədɔɹ, ən ɹipɔɹt tə ðə lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ. tə peɪdʒɹən naɪl pɝsənəli, tʃaɪl baɪɑɝ. jəl tɛl ɪm wʌt wɪv lɝn ə ðə sintʃæn; əl ɹaɪɾ ɪɾ aʊt fəɹ ju. bi ʃʊɹ i ʌndɝstænz ðət wi kən noʊ lɔŋɡɝ kaʊn ɑn ðə tɑɹ vəlɑn wɪtʃəz biɪŋ kɑntɛnt wɪð mənɪpjəleɪɾɪŋ ɪvɛns fɹəm ðə ʃædoʊz. ɪf ðeɪ faɪɾ oʊpənli fəɹ ðə sintʃæn, wɪl ʃʊɹli feɪs əm ɛlswɛɹ." hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. ðət læst wɑz ðə moʊst ɪmpɔɹɾənt ʌv ɔl. ðeɪ hæd tə noʊ ʌndɝ ðə doʊm ə tʃɹuθ ðət fəɹ ɔl ðɛɹ vɔntɪɾ oʊðz, ɛɛs sədaɪ wəd mɑɹtʃ ɪndə bæɾəl. ɪt ɡeɪv ɪm ə sɪŋkɪŋ filɪŋ, ə wɝld wɛɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ wildɪd ðə paʊɝ ɪn bæɾəl; hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ðəɾ i wəd ɹəɡɹɛt livɪŋ ɪt. bʌt ðəɹ wɑz wʌn mɔɹ mɛsədʒ i wɑntəd kæɹid tə æmədɔɹ. "ænd, baɪɑɝ . . . tɛl peɪdʒɹən naɪl haʊ wi wɝ juz baɪ ðə kwɛstʃənɝz."

"When you have found my son - he should be with Lord Captain Eamon Valda near Tar Valon - and told him, you will ride to Amador, and report to the Lord Captain Commander. To Pedron Niall personally, Child Byar. You will tell him what we have learned of the Seanchan; I will write it out for you. Be sure he understands that we can no longer count on the Tar Valon witches being content with manipulating events from the shadows. If they fight openly for the Seanchan, we will surely face them elsewhere." He hesitated. That last was the most important of all. They had to know under the Dome of Truth that for all their vaunted oaths, Aes Sedai would march into battle. It gave him a sinking feeling, a world where Aes Sedai wielded the Power in battle; he was not sure that he would regret leaving it. But there was one more message he wanted carried to Amador. "And, Byar . . . tell Pedron Niall how we were used by the Questioners."

"æz jə kəmænd, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən," baɪɑɝ sɛd, bʌt bɔɹnhəl saɪɾ ət ði ɪkspɹɛʃən ɑn ɪz feɪs. ðə mæn dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd. tə baɪɑɝ, ɔɹɾɝz wɝ tə bi oʊbeɪd wɛðɝ ðeɪ keɪm fɹəm ðə lɔɹd kæptən əɹ ðə kwɛstʃənɝz, wʌtɛvɝ ðeɪ wɝ.

"As you command, my Lord Captain," Byar said, but Bornhald sighed at the expression on his face. The man did not understand. To Byar, orders were to be obeyed whether they came from the Lord Captain or the Questioners, whatever they were.

"aɪ wɪl ɹaɪt ðəɾ aʊt fəɹ jə tə hæn tə peɪdʒɹən naɪl əz wɛl," hi sɛd. hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ haʊ mʌtʃ ɡʊɾ ɪt wəd də ɪn ɛni keɪs. ə θɔt keɪm tə hɪm, ən i fɹaʊn ət ði ɪn, wɛɹ səm ə hɪz mɛn wɝ laʊdli hæmɝɪŋ neɪlz θɹu ʃʌɾɝz ən dɔɹz. "pɛɹɪn," hi mʌɾɝd. "ðæt wɑz ɪz neɪm. pɛɹɪn, fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz."

"I will write that out for you to hand to Pedron Niall as well," he said. He was not sure how much good it would do in any case. A thought came to him, and he frowned at the inn, where some of his men were loudly hammering nails through shutters and doors. "Perrin," he muttered. "That was his name. Perrin, from the Two Rivers."

"ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnd, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən?"

"The Darkfriend, my Lord Captain?"

"pɝhæps, baɪɑɝ." hi wɑz nɑɾ ɪntaɪɝli sɝɾən, hɪmsɛlf, bʌt ʃʊɹli ə mæn u sim tə hæv wʊlvz faɪt fəɹ ɪm kəd bi nʌθɪŋ ɛls. sɝɾənli, ðɪs pɛɹɪn hæd kɪl tu ʌv ðə tʃɪlʒɹən. "aɪ θɔɾ aɪ sɔ hɪm wən wi ɹoʊɾ ɪn, bʌɾ aɪ də nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɛniwʌn əmʌŋ ðə pɹɪznɝz u lʊk laɪk ə blæksmɪθ."

"Perhaps, Byar." He was not entirely certain, himself, but surely a man who seemed to have wolves fight for him could be nothing else. Certainly, this Perrin had killed two of the Children. "I thought I saw him when we rode in, but I do not remember anyone among the prisoners who looked like a blacksmith."

"ðɛɹ blæksmɪθ lɛft ə mʌnθ əɡoʊ, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən. səm ə ðɛm wɝ kəmpleɪnɪŋ ðət ðeɪɾ əv bɪn ɡɔn bɪfɔɹ wi keɪm ɪf ðeɪ hæd nɑt hæd tə mɛn ðɛɹ kɑɹtwilz ðɛmsɛlvz. dʒju bɪliv ɪt wɑz ðə mæn pɛɹɪn, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən?"

"Their blacksmith left a month ago, my Lord Captain. Some of them were complaining that they'd have been gone before we came if they had not had to mend their cartwheels themselves. Do you believe it was the man Perrin, my Lord Captain?"

"huɛvɝ ɪt wɑz, hiz nɑɾ əkaʊntəd fɔɹ, noʊ? ən i meɪ kæɹi wɝɾ ʌv əs tə ðə sintʃæn."

"Whoever it was, he is not accounted for, no? And he may carry word of us to the Seanchan."

"eɪ dɑɹkfɹɛnd wəd ʃʊɹli də soʊ, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən."

"A Darkfriend would surely do so, my Lord Captain."

bɔɹnhəld ɡʌlp ðə læst ə ðə wɔɾɝ ən tɔs ðə kʌp əsaɪd. "ðɛɹ wɪl bi noʊ mil fəɹ ðə mɛn hɪɹ, baɪɑɝ. əl nɑt lɛt ðiz sintʃæn kætʃ mi næpɪŋ, wɛðɝ ɪts pɛɹɪn ə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz əɹ sʌmwʌn ɛls u wɔɹnz ðɛm. maʊn ðə lidʒən, tʃaɪl baɪɑɝ!"

Bornhald gulped the last of the water and tossed the cup aside. "There will be no meal for the men here, Byar. I will not let these Seanchan catch me napping, whether it is Perrin of the Two Rivers or someone else who warns them. Mount the legion, Child Byar!"

fɑɹ əbʌv ðɛɹ hɛdz, ə hjudʒ, wɪŋd ʃeɪp sɝkəld, ənnoʊɾɪst.

Far above their heads, a huge, winged shape circled, unnoticed.

ɪn ðə klɪɹɪŋ əmɪd ðə hɪltɑp θɪkɪt wɛɹ ðeɪ hæd meɪd ðɛɹ kæmp, ɹænd wɝk ðə fɔɹmz wɪð ɪz sɔɹd. hi wɑntəd tə kip fɹəm θɪŋkɪŋ. hi hæd hæɾ ɪz tʃænsəz tə sɝtʃ wɪð hʊɹɪn fəɹ feɪnz tʃɹeɪl; ðeɪ ɔl hæd, ɪn tuz ən θɹiz soʊ ðeɪ wəd nɑɾ ətʃɹækt ətɛnʃən, ən ðeɪ hæɾ ɔl faʊnd nʌθɪŋ soʊ fɑɹ. naʊ ðeɪ weɪɾəd fəɹ mæt ən pɛɹɪn tə kʌm bæk wɪð ðə snɪfɝ; ðeɪ ʃʊɾə bɪn bæk aʊɝz əɡoʊ.

In the clearing amid the hilltop thicket where they had made their camp, Rand worked the forms with his sword. He wanted to keep from thinking. He had had his chances to search with Hurin for Fain's trail; they all had, in twos and threes so they would not attract attention, and they had all found nothing so far. Now they waited for Mat and Perrin to come back with the sniffer; they should have been back hours ago.

lɔɪəl wɑz ɹiɾɪŋ, ʌv kɔɹs, ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ tɛlɪŋ ɪf ɪz ɪɹ-twɪtʃɪŋ wɑz oʊvɝ ɪz bʊk əɹ ðə skaʊɾɪŋ pɑɹɾiz leɪtnəs, bʌɾ ənoʊ ən moʊst ə ðə ʃaɪnɝən soʊlʒɝz sæt tɛnsli, ɔɪlɪŋ ðɛɹ sɔɹdz, əɹ kɛpt wɑtʃ θɹu ðə tʃɹiz əz ɪf ðeɪ ɪkspɛktəd sintʃæn tə əpɪɹ ɛni moʊmənt. oʊnli vɛɹɪn əpɪɹɾ ʌnkənsɝnd. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sæɾ ɑn ə lɔɡ bɪsaɪd ðɛɹ smɔl faɪɝ, mɝmɝɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf ən ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə dɝt wɪð ə lɔŋ stɪk; ɛvɹi soʊ ɔfən ʃi wəd ʃeɪk əɹ hɛɾ ən skɹʌb ɪɾ ɔl aʊt wɪð əɹ fʊɾ ən stɑɹɾ oʊvɝ əɡɛn. ɔl ðə hɔɹsəz wɝ sæɾəld ən ɹɛɾi tə ɡoʊ, ðə ʃaɪnɝənz' ænəməlz itʃ taɪd tə ə læns dʒɹɪvən ɪndə ðə ɡɹaʊnd.

Loial was reading, of course, and there was no telling if his ear-twitching was over his book or the scouting party's lateness, but Uno and most of the Shienaran soldiers sat tensely, oiling their swords, or kept watch through the trees as if they expected Seanchan to appear any moment. Only Verin appeared unconcerned. The Aes Sedai sat on a log beside their small fire, murmuring to herself and writing in the dirt with a long stick; every so often she would shake her head and scrub it all out with her foot and start over again. All the horses were saddled and ready to go, the Shienarans' animals each tied to a lance driven into the ground.

"hɛɹən weɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə ɹʌʃəz," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd. hi sæt wɪð ɪz bæk əɡɛnst ə tʃɹi, slaɪɾɪŋ ə ʃɑɹpənɪŋ stoʊn əlɔŋ ɪz sɔɹɾ ən wɑtʃɪŋ ɹænd. "ju ʃəd nɑt bi bɑðɝɪŋ wɪð ðət wʌn. ɪt livz jə kəmplitli oʊpən."

"Heron Wading in the Rushes," Ingtar said. He sat with his back against a tree, sliding a sharpening stone along his sword and watching Rand. "You should not be bothering with that one. It leaves you completely open."

fəɹ ən ɪnstən ɹænd bælənst ɑn ðə bɔl ʌv wʌn fʊt, sɔɹd hɛld ɹɪvɝst ɪn boʊθ hænz oʊvɝ ɪz hɛd, ðən ʃɪftəd smuðli tə ði ʌðɝ fʊt. "læn sɛz ɪts ɡʊd fəɹ dɪvɛləpɪŋ bæləns." ɪt wɑz nɑɾ izi kipɪŋ ɪz bæləns. ɪn ðə vɔɪɾ ɪɾ ɔfən simd i kəd meɪnteɪn ɪz ikwəlɪbɹiəm ətɑp ə ɹoʊlɪŋ boʊldɝ, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt dɛɹ əsum ðə vɔɪd. hi wɑntəd tə tu mʌtʃ tə tʃɹʌs hɪmsɛlf.

For an instant Rand balanced on the ball of one foot, sword held reversed in both hands over his head, then shifted smoothly to the other foot. "Lan says it's good for developing balance." It was not easy keeping his balance. In the void it often seemed he could maintain his equilibrium atop a rolling boulder, but he did not dare assume the void. He wanted to too much to trust himself.

"wʌt jə pɹæktəs tu ɔfən, jə jus wɪθaʊt θɪŋkɪŋ. jəl pʊt jəɹ sɔɹɾ ɪn ði ʌðɝ mæn wɪð ðæt, ɪf jəɹ kwɪk, bʌt nɑt bɪfɔɹ hiz ɪz θɹu jəɹ ɹɪbz. jə ɑɹ pɹæktəkli ɪnvaɪɾɪŋ hɪm. aɪ doʊn θɪŋk aɪ kəd si ə mæn feɪs mi soʊ oʊpən ən nɑt pʊt maɪ sɔɹɾ ɪn hɪm, ivən noʊɪŋ i maɪt stʃɹaɪk hoʊm ət mi ɪf aɪ dɪd."

"What you practice too often, you use without thinking. You will put your sword in the other man with that, if you're quick, but not before he has his through your ribs. You are practically inviting him. I don't think I could see a man face me so open and not put my sword in him, even knowing he might strike home at me if I did."

"ɪts oʊnli fəɹ bæləns, ɪŋtʃɹ." ɹænd weɪvɝɾ ɑn wʌn fʊt, ən hæd tə pʊt ði ʌðɝ daʊn tə kip fɹəm fɔlɪŋ. hi slæm ðə bleɪɾ ɪndə ɪts skæbɝɾ ən pɪkt ʌp ðə ɡɹeɪ kloʊk ðət hæd bɪn ɪz dɪsɡaɪz. ɪt wɑz mɔθ-iɾən, ən ɹæɡəɾ ɝaʊn ðə bɑɾəm, bʌt laɪnd wɪð θɪk flis, ən ðə wɪnd wɑz pɪkɪŋ ʌp, koʊld ən aʊɾ ə ðə wɛst. "aɪ wɪʃ ðeɪd kʌm bæk."

"It's only for balance, Ingtar." Rand wavered on one foot, and had to put the other down to keep from falling. He slammed the blade into its scabbard and picked up the gray cloak that had been his disguise. It was moth-eaten, and ragged around the bottom, but lined with thick fleece, and the wind was picking up, cold and out of the west. "I wish they'd come back."

əz ɪf ɪz wɪʃ hæd bɪn ə sɪɡnəl, ənoʊ spoʊk ʌp wɪð kwaɪəɾ ɝdʒənsi. "blʌɾi hɔɹsmən kʌmɪŋ, maɪ lɔɹd." skæbɝdz ɹæɾəld əz mɛn u dɪd nɑɾ ɔlɹɛɾi hæv ðɛɹ bleɪdz aʊt bɛɹd ðɛm. səm lɛpt ɪndə ðɛɹ sæɾəlz, snætʃɪŋ ʌp lænsɪz.

As if his wish had been a signal, Uno spoke up with quiet urgency. "Bloody horsemen coming, my Lord." Scabbards rattled as men who did not already have their blades out bared them. Some leaped into their saddles, snatching up lances.

ðə tɛnʃən feɪɾəd əz hʊɹɪn lɛd ði ʌðɝz ɪndə ðə klɪɹɪŋ əɾ ə tʃɹɑt, ən keɪm əɡɛn əz i spoʊk. "wi faʊn ðə tʃɹeɪl, lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹ."

The tension faded as Hurin led the others into the clearing at a trot, and came again as he spoke. "We found the trail, Lord Ingtar."

"wi fɑloʊɾ ɪɾ ɔlmoʊs tə fɑlm," mæt sɛɾ əz i dɪsmaʊntɪd. ə flʌʃ ɪn ɪz peɪl tʃiks simd ə mɑkɪŋ ə hɛlθ; ðə skɪn wɑz taɪɾ oʊvɝ ɪz skʌl. ðə ʃaɪnɝənz ɡæðɝɾ ɝaʊnd, əz ɪksaɪɾəd əz i wɑz. "ɪts dʒʌs feɪn, bʌt ðəɹ ɪzən ɛniwɛɹ ɛls i kəd bi ɡoʊɪŋ. hi mʌst əv ðə dæɡɝ."

"We followed it almost to Falme," Mat said as he dismounted. A flush in his pale cheeks seemed a mocking of health; the skin was tight over his skull. The Shienarans gathered around, as excited as he was. "It's just Fain, but there isn't anywhere else he could be going. He must have the dagger."

"wi faʊnd waɪtkloʊks, tu," pɛɹɪn sɛd, swɪŋɪŋ daʊn fɹəm ɪz sæɾəl. "hʌnʒɹədz ə ðɛm."

"We found Whitecloaks, too," Perrin said, swinging down from his saddle. "Hundreds of them."

"waɪtkloʊks?" ɪŋtʃɹ ɪkskleɪmd, fɹaʊnɪŋ. "hɪɹ? wɛl, ɪf ðeɪ də nɑt tʃɹʌbəl ʌs, wɪl nɑt tʃɹʌbəl ðɛm. pɝhæps ɪf ðə sintʃæn ɑɹ ɑkjəpaɪd wɪð ðɛm, ɪɾəl hɛlp əs ɹitʃ ðə hɔɹn." hɪz aɪz fɛl ɑn vɛɹɪn, stɪl siɾəd baɪ ðə faɪɝ. "aɪ səpoʊz jəl tɛl mi aɪ ʃʊɾə lɪsən tə ju, ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðə mæn dɪd ɡoʊ tə fɑlm."

"Whitecloaks?" Ingtar exclaimed, frowning. "Here? Well, if they do not trouble us, we will not trouble them. Perhaps if the Seanchan are occupied with them, it will help us reach the Horn." His eyes fell on Verin, still seated by the fire. "I suppose you will tell me I should have listened to you, Aes Sedai. The man did go to Falme."

"ðə wil wivz əz ðə wil wɪlz," vɛɹɪn sɛd plɑtʃədli. "wɪð tɑvɝən, wʌt hæpənz ɪz wʌt wɑz mɛn tə hæpən. ɪt meɪ bi ðə pæɾɝn dɪmændəd ðiz ɛkstʃɹə deɪz. ðə pæɾɝn pʊts ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪn ɪts pleɪs pɹɪsaɪsli, ən wən wi tʃɹaɪ tə ɔltɝ ɪt, ɪspɛʃli ɪf tɑvɝən ɑɹ ɪnvɑlvd, ðə wivɪŋ tʃeɪnʒəz tə pʊɾ əs bæk ɪndə ðə pæɾɝn əz wi wɝ mɛn tə bi." ðəɹ wɑz ən ənizi saɪləns ðət ʃi dɪd nɑt sim tə noʊɾəs; ʃi skɛtʃt ɑn aɪdli wɪð ðə stɪk. "naʊ, haʊɛvɝ, aɪ θɪŋk pɝhæps wi ʃəd meɪk plænz. ðə pæɾɝn əz bɹɔɾ əs tə fɑlm ət læst. ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ əz bɪn teɪkən tə fɑlm."

"The Wheel weaves as the Wheel wills," Verin said placidly. "With ta'veren, what happens is what was meant to happen. It may be the Pattern demanded these extra days. The Pattern puts everything in its place precisely, and when we try to alter it, especially if ta'veren are involved, the weaving changes to put us back into the Pattern as we were meant to be." There was an uneasy silence that she did not seem to notice; she sketched on idly with the stick. "Now, however, I think perhaps we should make plans. The Pattern has brought us to Falme at last. The Horn of Valere has been taken to Falme."

ɪŋtʃɹ skwɑɾɪd əkɹɔs ðə faɪɝ fɹəm hɝ. "wɛn ɪnʌf pipəl seɪ ðə seɪm θɪŋ, aɪ tɛn tə bɪliv ɪt, ən ðə loʊkəl pipəl seɪ ðə sintʃæn də nɑt sim tə kɛɹ u kʌmz əɹ ɡoʊz ɪn fɑlm. əl teɪk hʊɹɪn ən ə fju ʌðɝz ɪndə ðə taʊn. wʌns i fɑloʊz feɪnz tʃɹeɪl tə ðə hɔɹn . . . wɛl, ðən wi ʃæl si wʌt wi ʃæl si."

Ingtar squatted across the fire from her. "When enough people say the same thing, I tend to believe it, and the local people say the Seanchan do not seem to care who comes or goes in Falme. I will take Hurin and a few others into the town. Once he follows Fain's trail to the Horn . . . well, then we shall see what we shall see."

wɪð əɹ fʊt, vɛɹɪn skɹʌbd aʊɾ ə wil ʃi hæd dʒɹɔn ɪn ðə dɝt. ɪn ɪts pleɪs ʃi dʒɹu tu ʃɔɹt laɪnz ðət tʌtʃt ət wʌn ɛnd. "ɪŋtʃɹ ən hʊɹɪn. ən mæt, əz i kən sɛns ðə dæɡɝ ɪf i kʌmz kloʊs ɪnʌf. jə də wɑnə ɡoʊ, doʊn ju, mæt?"

With her foot, Verin scrubbed out a wheel she had drawn in the dirt. In its place she drew two short lines that touched at one end. "Ingtar and Hurin. And Mat, as he can sense the dagger if he comes close enough. You do want to go, don't you, Mat?"

mæt əpɪɹd tɔɹn, bʌɾ i ɡeɪv ə dʒɝki nɑd. "aɪ hæv tə, doʊn aɪ? aɪ hæv tə faɪn ðət dæɡɝ."

Mat appeared torn, but he gave a jerky nod. "I have to, don't I? I have to find that dagger."

ə θɝd laɪn meɪɾ ə bɝd tʃɹæk. vɛɹɪn lʊk saɪdweɪz ət ɹænd.

A third line made a bird track. Verin looked sideways at Rand.

"aɪl ɡoʊ," hi sɛd. "ðæɾ ɪz waɪ aɪ keɪm." ən ɑd laɪɾ əpɪɹɾ ɪn ði ɛɛs sədaɪz aɪz, ə noʊɪŋ ɡlɪmɝ ðət meɪɾ ɪm ənizi. "tə hɛlp mæt faɪn ðə dæɡɝ," hi sɛd ʃɑɹpli, "æn ɪŋtʃɹ faɪn ðə hɔɹn." ən feɪn, hi æɾəd tə hɪmsɛlf. aɪ hæv tə faɪn feɪn ɪf ɪɾ ɪzən ɔlɹɛɾi tu leɪt.

"I'll go," he said. "That is why I came." An odd light appeared in the Aes Sedai's eyes, a knowing glimmer that made him uneasy. "To help Mat find the dagger," he said sharply, "and Ingtar find the Horn." And Fain, he added to himself. I have to find Fain if it isn't already too late.

vɛɹɪn skɹætʃt ə fɔɹθ laɪn, tɝnɪŋ ðə bɝd tʃɹæk tə ə lɑpsaɪɾɪd stɑɹ. "æn u ɛls?" ʃi sɛd sɔfli. ʃi hɛl ðə stɪk pɔɪzd.

Verin scratched a fourth line, turning the bird track to a lopsided star. "And who else?" she said softly. She held the stick poised.

"mi," pɛɹɪn sɛd, ə hɛɹ bɪfɔɹ lɔɪəl tʃaɪmd ɪn wɪð, "aɪ θɪŋk aɪ wəd laɪk tə ɡoʊ, tu," ən ənoʊ ən ði ʌðɝ ʃaɪnɝənz ɔl bɪɡæn klæmɝɪŋ tə dʒɔɪn.

"Me," Perrin said, a hair before Loial chimed in with, "I think I would like to go, too," and Uno and the other Shienarans all began clamoring to join.

"pɛɹɪn spoʊk fɝst," vɛɹɪn sɛd, əz ɪf ðət sɛɾəld ɪt. ʃi æɾəd ə fɪfθ laɪn ən dʒɹu ə sɝkəl ɝaʊn ɔl faɪv. ðə hɛɹ ɑn ɹændz nɛk stɝd; ɪt wɑz ðə seɪm wil ʃi hæd ɹʌbd aʊɾ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs. "faɪv ɹaɪd fɔɹθ," ʃi mɝmɝd.

"Perrin spoke first," Verin said, as if that settled it. She added a fifth line and drew a circle around all five. The hair on Rand's neck stirred; it was the same wheel she had rubbed out in the first place. "Five ride forth," she murmured.

"aɪ ɹɪli wəd laɪk tə si fɑlm," lɔɪəl sɛd. "aɪv nɛvɝ sin ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən. bɪsaɪdz, aɪ kən kæɹi ðə tʃɛst, ɪf ðə hɔɹn ɪz stɪl ɪn ɪt."

"I really would like to see Falme," Loial said. "I've never seen the Aryth Ocean. Besides, I can carry the chest, if the Horn is still in it."

"jud bɛɾɝ ɪnklud mi ət list, maɪ lɔɹd," ənoʊ sɛd. "ju ən lɔɹd ɹænd wɪl niɾ ənʌðɝ sɔɹɾ ət jəɹ bæks ɪf ðoʊz blʌɾi sintʃæn tʃɹaɪ tə stɑp ju." ðə ɹɛst ə ðə soʊlʒɝz ɹʌmbəl ðə seɪm sɛntəmənt.

"You'd better include me at least, my Lord," Uno said. "You and Lord Rand will need another sword at your backs if those bloody Seanchan try to stop you." The rest of the soldiers rumbled the same sentiment.

"du nɑt bi sɪli," vɛɹɪn sɛd ʃɑɹpli. hɝ stɛɹ saɪlənst əm ɔl. "ɔl ə jə kænɑt ɡoʊ. noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ ənkɛɹɪŋ ðə sintʃæn ɑɹ əbaʊt stʃɹeɪnʒɝz, ðəl ʃʊɹli teɪk noʊɾəs ə twɛnti soʊlʒɝz, ən jə lʊk laɪk nʌθɪŋ ɛls ivən wɪθaʊɾ ɑɹmɝ. ən wʌn əɹ tu ʌv jəl meɪk noʊ dɪfɝəns. faɪv ɪz fju ɪnʌf tə ɛntɝ wɪθaʊɾ ətʃɹæktɪŋ ətɛnʃən, ən ɪts fɪɾɪŋ ðət θɹi ʌv əm ʃəd bi ðə θɹi tɑvɝən əmʌŋ ʌs. noʊ, lɔɪəl, jə mʌst steɪ bɪhaɪnd, tu. ðəɹ ɑɹ noʊ oʊɡiɝ ɑn toʊmən hɛd. jə wəɾ ətʃɹækt əz mɛni aɪz əz ɔl ðə ɹɛs pʊt təɡɛðɝ."

"Do not be silly," Verin said sharply. Her stare silenced them all. "All of you cannot go. No matter how uncaring the Seanchan are about strangers, they will surely take notice of twenty soldiers, and you look like nothing else even without armor. And one or two of you will make no difference. Five is few enough to enter without attracting attention, and it is fitting that three of them should be the three ta'veren among us. No, Loial, you must stay behind, too. There are no Ogier on Toman Head. You would attract as many eyes as all the rest put together."

"wʌɾ əbaʊt ju?" ɹænd æskt.

"What about you?" Rand asked.

vɛɹɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "ju fɝɡɛt ðə deɪmeɪn." hɝ maʊθ twɪstəɾ ɝaʊn ðə wɝɾ ɪn dɪsteɪst. "ði oʊnli weɪ aɪ kəd hɛlp jə wəd bi ɪf aɪ tʃænəl ðə paʊɝ, ən ðət wəd bi noʊ hɛlp əɾ ɔl ɪf aɪ bɹɔt ðoʊz daʊn ɑn ju. ivən ɪf ðeɪ wɝ nɑt kloʊs ɪnʌf tə si, wʌn maɪt wɛl fil ə wʊmən - əɹ ə mæn, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ - tʃænəlɪŋ, ɪf kɛɹ wɑz nɑt teɪkən tə kip ðə paʊɝ tʃænəl smɔl." ʃi dɪd nɑt lʊk ət ɹænd; tə hɪm, ʃi simd ɑstənteɪʃəs ɪn nɑt duɪŋ soʊ, ən mæt ən pɛɹɪn wɝ sʌɾənli ɪntɛn ɑn ðɛɹ oʊn fit.

Verin shook her head. "You forget the damane." Her mouth twisted around the word in distaste. "The only way I could help you would be if I channeled the Power, and that would be no help at all if I brought those down on you. Even if they were not close enough to see, one might well feel a woman - or a man, for that matter - channeling, if care was not taken to keep the Power channeled small." She did not look at Rand; to him, she seemed ostentatious in not doing so, and Mat and Perrin were suddenly intent on their own feet.

"ə mæn," ɪŋtʃɹ snɔɹɾɪd. "vɛɹɪn sədaɪ, waɪ æd pɹɑbləmz? wɪv ɪnʌf ɔlɹɛɾi wɪθaʊt səpoʊzɪŋ mɛn tʃænəlɪŋ. bʌɾ ɪt wəd bi wɛl ɪf jə wɝ ðɛɹ. ɪf wɪv niɾ ə jə - "

"A man," Ingtar snorted. "Verin Sedai, why add problems? We have enough already without supposing men channeling. But it would be well if you were there. If we have need of you - "

"noʊ, jə faɪv mʌst ɡoʊ əloʊn." hɝ fʊt skɹʌbd əkɹɔs ðə wil dʒɹɔn ɪn ðə dɝt, pɑɹʃəli əbliɾɝeɪtɪŋ ɪt. ʃi stʌɾid itʃ ə ðɛm ɪn tɝn, ɪntɛn ən fɹaʊnɪŋ. "faɪv wɪl ɹaɪd fɔɹθ."

"No, you five must go alone." Her foot scrubbed across the wheel drawn in the dirt, partially obliterating it. She studied each of them in turn, intent and frowning. "Five will ride forth."

fəɹ ə moʊmən ɪt sim ðəɾ ɪŋtʃɹ wəɾ æsk əɡɛn, bʌt miɾɪŋ əɹ lɛvəl ɡeɪz, hi ʃɹʌɡd ən tɝn tə hʊɹɪn. "haʊ lɔŋ tə ɹitʃ fɑlm?"

For a moment it seemed that Ingtar would ask again, but meeting her level gaze, he shrugged and turned to Hurin. "How long to reach Falme?"

ðə snɪfɝ skɹætʃt ɪz hɛd. "ɪf wi lɛf naʊ ən ɹoʊd θɹu ðə naɪt, wi kəd bi ðəɹ baɪ sʌnɹaɪz təmɑɹoʊ mɔɹnɪŋ."

The sniffer scratched his head. "If we left now and rode through the night, we could be there by sunrise tomorrow morning."

"ðɛn ðəɾ ɪz wʌt wɪl du. əl weɪs noʊ mɔɹ taɪm. ɔl ə jə sæɾəl jəɹ hɔɹsəz. ənoʊ, aɪ wɑn jə tə bɹɪŋ ði ʌðɝz əlɔŋ bɪhaɪn ʌs, bʌt kip aʊɾ ə saɪt, ən də nɑt lɛɾ ɛniwʌn. . . ."

"Then that is what we will do. I'll waste no more time. All of you saddle your horses. Uno, I want you to bring the others along behind us, but keep out of sight, and do not let anyone. . . ."

ɹænd pɪɹɾ ət ðə skɛtʃt wil əz ɪŋtʃɹ wɛn ɑn wɪð ɪz ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz. ɪt wɑz ə bɹoʊkən wil, naʊ, wɪð oʊnli fɔɹ spoʊks. fəɹ səm ɹizən ðət meɪɾ ɪm ʃɪvɝ. hi ɹilaɪz vɛɹɪn wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm, dɑɹk aɪz bɹaɪɾ ən ɪntɛn laɪk ə bɝdz. ɪt tʊk ən ɛfɝt tə pʊl ɪz ɡeɪz əweɪ ən bɪɡɪn ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪz θɪŋz təɡɛðɝ.

Rand peered at the sketched wheel as Ingtar went on with his instructions. It was a broken wheel, now, with only four spokes. For some reason that made him shiver. He realized Verin was watching him, dark eyes bright and intent like a bird's. It took an effort to pull his gaze away and begin getting his things together.

jəɹ lɛɾɪŋ fænsiz teɪk ju, hi toʊl hɪmsɛlf ɪɹɪɾəbli. ʃi kæn də ɛniθɪŋ ɪf ʃi ɪzən ðɛɹ.

You're letting fancies take you, he told himself irritably. She can't do anything if she isn't there.


tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾifaɪv


CHAPTER 45

bleɪdmæstɝ


Blademaster

ðə ɹaɪzɪŋ sʌn pʊʃt ɪts kɹɪmzən ɛdʒ əbʌv ðə hɝaɪzən ən sɛn lɔŋ ʃædoʊz daʊn ðə kɑbəlstoʊn stʃɹits ə fɑlm təwɔɹd ðə hɑɹbɝ. ə si bɹiz bɛn ðə smoʊk ə bɹɛkfəs kʊk faɪɝz ɪnlæn fɹəm ðə tʃɪmniz. oʊnli ði ɝli ɹaɪzɝz wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi aʊɾ ə dɔɹz, ðɛɹ bɹɛθ meɪkɪŋ stim ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ koʊld. kəmpɛɹd tə ðə kɹaʊdz ðət wəd fɪl ðə stʃɹits ɪn ənʌðɝ aʊɝ, ðə taʊn sim nɪɹli ɛmpti.

The rising sun pushed its crimson edge above the horizon and sent long shadows down the cobblestone streets of Falme toward the harbor. A sea breeze bent the smoke of breakfast cook fires inland from the chimneys. Only the early risers were already out of doors, their breath making steam in the morning cold. Compared to the crowds that would fill the streets in another hour, the town seemed nearly empty.

sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ən ʌpɛndəd bæɹəl ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ə stɪl-kloʊzd aɪɝənmɑŋɡɝz ʃɑp, nɪneɪiv wɔɹmd əɹ hænz ʌndɝ əɹ ɑɹmz ən sɝveɪɾ əɹ ɑɹmi. mɪn sæɾ ɑn ə dɔɹstɛp əkɹɔs ðə weɪ, swɑðd ɪn əɹ sintʃæn kloʊk ən iɾɪŋ ə ɹɪŋkəl plʌm, ən ɪleɪn ɪn əɹ flis koʊt hʌɾəld ət ði ɛdʒ ʌv ən æli dʒʌs daʊn ðə stʃɹit fɹəm hɝ. ə lɑɹdʒ sæk, pɪlfɝd fɹəm ðə dɑks, leɪ nitli foʊldəd bɪsaɪd mɪn. maɪ ɑɹmi, nɪneɪiv θɔt ɡɹɪmli. bʌt ðəɹ ɪzən ɛnibəɾi ɛls.

Sitting on an upended barrel in front of a still-closed ironmonger's shop, Nynaeve warmed her hands under her arms and surveyed her army. Min sat on a doorstep across the way, swathed in her Seanchan cloak and eating a wrinkled plum, and Elayne in her fleece coat huddled at the edge of an alley just down the street from her. A large sack, pilfered from the docks, lay neatly folded beside Min. My army, Nynaeve thought grimly. But there isn't anybody else.

ʃi kɑt saɪɾ ʌv ə sʌldəm ən ə deɪmeɪn klaɪmɪŋ ðə stʃɹit, ə jɛloʊ-hɛɹd wʊmən wɛɹɪŋ ðə bɹeɪsləɾ ən ə dɑɹk wʊmən ðə kɑlɝ, boʊθ jɔnɪŋ slipəli. ðə fju fɑlmɛn ʃɛɹɪŋ ðə stʃɹit wɪð əm əvɝɾəd ðɛɹ aɪz ən ɡeɪv əm ə waɪd bɝθ. əz fɑɹ əz ʃi kəd si daʊn təwɔɹd ðə hɑɹbɝ, ðəɹ wɑz nɑɾ ənʌðɝ sintʃæn. ʃi dɪd nɑt tɝn əɹ hɛd ði ʌðɝ weɪ. ɪnstɛd, ʃi stʃɹɛtʃt ən ʃɹʌɡd əz ɪf wɝkɪŋ koʊld ʃoʊldɝz bɪfɔɹ sɛɾəlɪŋ bæk əz ʃi hæd bɪn.

She caught sight of a sul'dam and a damane climbing the street, a yellow-haired woman wearing the bracelet and a dark woman the collar, both yawning sleepily. The few Falmen sharing the street with them averted their eyes and gave them a wide berth. As far as she could see down toward the harbor, there was not another Seanchan. She did not turn her head the other way. Instead, she stretched and shrugged as if working cold shoulders before settling back as she had been.

mɪn tɔst əɹ hæf-iɾən plʌm əsaɪd, ɡlæns kæʒəwəli ʌp ðə stʃɹit, ən lin bæk ɑn ðə dɔɹpoʊst. ðə weɪ wɑz klɪɹ ðɛɹ, tu, əɹ ʃi wʊɾə pʊɾ əɹ hænz ɑn əɹ niz. mɪn hæd stɑɹɾəd ɹʌbɪŋ əɹ hænz nɝvəsli, ən nɪneɪiv ɹilaɪz ðəɾ ɪleɪn wɑz naʊ baʊnsɪŋ iɡɝli ɑn əɹ toʊz.

Min tossed her half-eaten plum aside, glanced casually up the street, and leaned back on the doorpost. The way was clear there, too, or she would have put her hands on her knees. Min had started rubbing her hands nervously, and Nynaeve realized that Elayne was now bouncing eagerly on her toes.

ɪf ðeɪ ɡɪv əs əweɪ, əl θʌmp boʊθ ðɛɹ hɛdz. bʌt ʃi nu ɪf ðeɪ wɝ dɪskʌvɝd, ɪt wəd bi ðə sintʃæn u wəd seɪ wʌt hæpən tə ɔl θɹi ʌv ðɛm. ʃi wɑz ɔl tu əwɛɹ ðət ʃi hæd noʊ ɹil noʊʃən ʌv wɛðɝ wʌt ʃi plænd wəd wɝk əɹ nɑt. ɪt kəɾ izəli bi hɝ oʊn feɪljɝ ðət wəd ɡɪv əm əweɪ. wʌns əɡɛn ʃi ɹizɑlv ðəɾ ɪf ɛniθɪŋ wɛn ɹɔŋ, ʃi wəd sʌmhaʊ pʊl ətɛnʃən tə hɝsɛlf waɪl mɪn ən ɪleɪn ɪskeɪpt. ʃi hæd toʊld əm tə ɹʌn ɪf ɛniθɪŋ wɛn ɹɔŋ, ən lɛɾ əm θɪŋk ʃi wəd ɹʌn, tu. wʌt ʃi wəd də ðɛn, ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ. ɪksɛpt aɪ woʊn lɛɾ əm teɪk mi əlaɪv. pliz, laɪt, nɑt ðæt.

If they give us away, I'll thump both their heads. But she knew if they were discovered, it would be the Seanchan who would say what happened to all three of them. She was all too aware that she had no real notion of whether what she planned would work or not. It could easily be her own failure that would give them away. Once again she resolved that if anything went wrong, she would somehow pull attention to herself while Min and Elayne escaped. She had told them to run if anything went wrong, and let them think she would run, too. What she would do then, she did not know. Except I won't let them take me alive. Please, Light, not that.

sʌldəm ən deɪmeɪn keɪm ʌp ðə stʃɹiɾ əntɪl ðeɪ wɝ bɹækəɾɪd baɪ ðə θɹi weɪɾɪŋ wɪmən. ə dʌzən fɑlmɛn wɔkt waɪɾ ə ðə lɪŋk pɛɹ.

Sul'dam and damane came up the street until they were bracketed by the three waiting women. A dozen Falmen walked wide of the linked pair.

nɪneɪiv ɡæðɝɾ ɔl ə hɝ æŋɡɝ. liʃt wʌnz ən liʃ hoʊldɝz. ðeɪ hæd pʊt ðɛɹ fɪlθi kɑlɝ ɑn ɛɡwinz nɛk, ən ðeɪ wəd pʊɾ ɪɾ ɑn hɝz, ən ɪleɪnz, ɪf ðeɪ kʊd. ʃi hæd meɪd mɪn tɛl əɹ haʊ sʌldəm ɛnfɔɹs ðɛɹ wɪl. ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ mɪn hæd kɛp səm bæk, ðə wɝst, bʌt wʌt ʃi toʊld wɑz ɪnʌf tə hit nɪneɪiv tə waɪt-hɑt fjʊɹi. ɪn ən ɪnstən ə waɪt blɑsəm ɑn ə blæk, θɔɹni bɹæntʃ hæɾ oʊpən tə laɪt, tə seɪaɪdɑɹ, ən ðə wʌn paʊɝ fɪl hɝ. ʃi nu ðəɹ wɑz ə ɡloʊ ɝaʊn hɝ, fəɹ ðoʊz u kəd si ɪt. ðə peɪl-skɪn sʌldəm ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt, ən ðə dɑɹk deɪmeɪnz maʊθ fɛl oʊpən, bʌt nɪneɪiv ɡeɪv əm noʊ tʃæns. ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə tʃɹɪkəl ə ðə paʊɝ ðət ʃi tʃænəld, bʌt ʃi kɹækt ɪt, ə wɪp snæpɪŋ ə dʌs moʊɾ aʊɾ ə ði ɛɹ.

Nynaeve gathered all of her anger. Leashed Ones and Leash Holders. They had put their filthy collar on Egwene's neck, and they would put it on hers, and Elayne's, if they could. She had made Min tell her how sul'dam enforced their will. She was sure Min had kept some back, the worst, but what she told was enough to heat Nynaeve to white-hot fury. In an instant a white blossom on a black, thorny branch had opened to light, to saidar, and the One Power filled her. She knew there was a glow around her, for those who could see it. The pale-skinned sul'dam gave a start, and the dark damane's mouth fell open, but Nynaeve gave them no chance. It was only a trickle of the Power that she channeled, but she cracked it, a whip snapping a dust mote out of the air.

ðə sɪlvɝ kɑlɝ spɹæŋ oʊpən ən klæɾɝd tə ðə kɑbəlstoʊnz. nɪneɪiv hivd ə saɪ ʌv ɹɪlif ivən əz ʃi lɛp tə hɝ fit.

The silver collar sprang open and clattered to the cobblestones. Nynaeve heaved a sigh of relief even as she leaped to her feet.

ðə sʌldəm stɛɹɾ ət ðə fɔlən kɑlɝ əz ɪf əɾ ə pɔɪzənəs sneɪk. ðə deɪmeɪn pʊɾ ə ʃeɪkɪŋ hæn tə hɝ θɹoʊt, bʌt bɪfɔɹ ðə wʊmən ɪn ðə laɪtnɪŋ-mɑɹk dʒɹɛs hæd taɪm tə muv, ðə deɪmeɪn tɝn ən pʌntʃt əɹ ɪn ðə feɪs; ðə sʌldəmz niz bʌkəld, ən ʃi ɔlmoʊs fɛl.

The sul'dam stared at the fallen collar as if at a poisonous snake. The damane put a shaking hand to her throat, but before the woman in the lightning-marked dress had time to move, the damane turned and punched her in the face; the sul'dam's knees buckled, and she almost fell.

"ɡʊd fəɹ ju!" ɪleɪn ʃaʊɾəd. ʃi wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ɹʌnɪŋ fɔɹwɝd, tu, ən soʊ wɑz mɪn.

"Good for you!" Elayne shouted. She was already running forward, too, and so was Min.

bɪfɔɹ ɛni ʌv əm ɹitʃt ðə tu wɪmən, ðə deɪmeɪn tʊk wʌn stɑɹɾəld lʊk ɝaʊnd, ðən ɹæn əz hɑɹɾ əz ʃi kʊd.

Before any of them reached the two women, the damane took one startled look around, then ran as hard as she could.

"wi woʊn hɝt ju!" ɪleɪn kɔld æftɝ hɝ. "wi ɑɹ fɹɛnz!"

"We won't hurt you!" Elayne called after her. "We are friends!"

"bi kwaɪət!" nɪneɪiv hɪst. ʃi pɹədust ə hændfʊl ə ɹæɡz fɹəm əɹ pɑkəɾ ən ɹuθləsli stʌft əm ɪndə ðə ɡeɪpɪŋ maʊθ ə ðə stɪl-stæɡɝɪŋ sʌldəm. mɪn heɪstəli ʃʊk aʊt ðə sæk ɪn ə klaʊɾ ə dʌst ən plʌnʒd ɪɾ oʊvɝ ðə sʌldəmz hɛd, ʃɹaʊɾɪŋ ðə wʊmən tə ðə weɪst. "wi ɑɹ ɔlɹɛɾi ətʃɹæktɪŋ tu mʌtʃ ətɛnʃən."

"Be quiet!" Nynaeve hissed. She produced a handful of rags from her pocket and ruthlessly stuffed them into the gaping mouth of the still-staggering sul'dam. Min hastily shook out the sack in a cloud of dust and plunged it over the sul'dam's head, shrouding the woman to the waist. "We are already attracting too much attention."

ɪt wɑz tʃɹu, ən jɛt nɑɾ ɪntaɪɝli tʃɹu. ðə fɔɹ ə ðɛm stʊɾ ɪn ə ɹæpədli ɛmptiɪŋ stʃɹit, bʌt ðə pipəl u hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd tə bi ɛlswɛɹ wɝ əvɔɪɾɪŋ lʊkɪŋ ət ðɛm. nɪneɪiv hæd bɪn kaʊntɪŋ ɑn ðət - pipəl duɪŋ ðɛɹ bɛs tə ɪɡnɔɹ ɛniθɪŋ ðət hæd tə də wɪð sintʃæn - tə ɡeɪn əm ə fju moʊməns. ðeɪ wəd tɔk ɪvɛntʃəwəli, bʌɾ ɪn wɪspɝz; ɪt maɪt teɪk aʊɝz fəɹ ðə sintʃæn tə lɝn ɛniθɪŋ hæd hæpənd.

It was true, and yet not entirely true. The four of them stood in a rapidly emptying street, but the people who had decided to be elsewhere were avoiding looking at them. Nynaeve had been counting on that - people doing their best to ignore anything that had to do with Seanchan - to gain them a few moments. They would talk eventually, but in whispers; it might take hours for the Seanchan to learn anything had happened.

ðə hʊɾɪd wʊmən bɪɡæn tə stʃɹʌɡəl, meɪkɪŋ ɹæɡ-mʌfəld ʃaʊts fɹəm ðə sæk, bʌt nɪneɪiv ən mɪn θɹu ðɛɹ ɑɹmz ɝaʊn əɹ ən ɹɛsəld əɹ təwɔɹɾ ə nɪɹbaɪ æli. ðə liʃ ən kɑlɝ tʃɹeɪld əkɹɔs ðə kɑbəlstoʊnz bɪhaɪn ðɛm, klɪŋkɪŋ.

The hooded woman began to struggle, making rag-muffled shouts from the sack, but Nynaeve and Min threw their arms around her and wrestled her toward a nearby alley. The leash and collar trailed across the cobblestones behind them, clinking.

"pɪk ɪɾ ʌp," nɪneɪiv snæpt əɾ ɪleɪn. "ɪt woʊn baɪt ju!"

"Pick it up," Nynaeve snapped at Elayne. "It won't bite you!"

ɪleɪn tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, ðən ɡæðɝd ðə sɪlvɝ mɛɾəl dʒɪnʒɝli, əz ɪf ʃi fɪɹɾ ɪt vɛɹi wɛl maɪt. nɪneɪiv fɛl səm sɪmpəθi, bʌt nɑt mʌtʃ; ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɹɛstəɾ ɑn itʃ ə ðɛm duɪŋ əz ðeɪ hæd plænd.

Elayne took a deep breath, then gathered the silver metal gingerly, as if she feared it very well might. Nynaeve felt some sympathy, but not much; everything rested on each of them doing as they had planned.

ðə sʌldəm kɪkt ən tʃɹaɪd tə θɹoʊ hɝsɛlf fɹi, bʌt bɪtwin ðɛm, nɪneɪiv ən mɪn fɔɹst əɹ əlɔŋ, daʊn ði æli ɪndə ənʌðɝ, slaɪtli waɪɾɝ pæsədʒ bɪhaɪn haʊsəz, tə jɛɾ ənʌðɝ æli ən ət læst ɪndə ə ɹʌf wʊɾən ʃɛd ðət hæɾ əpɛɹənli wʌns haʊz tu hɔɹsəz, baɪ ðə stɔlz. fju kəɾ əfɔɹd tə kip hɔɹsəz sɪns ðə sintʃæn keɪm, ən ɪn ə deɪ ʌv nɪneɪivz wɑtʃɪŋ, noʊ wʌn hæd ɡɔn nɪɹ ɪt. ði ɪntɪɹiɝ hæɾ ə mʌsti dʌstinəs ðət spoʊk ʌv əbændənmənt. əz sun əz ðeɪ wɝ ɪnsaɪd, ɪleɪn dʒɹɑp ðə sɪlvɝ liʃ ən waɪpt əɹ hænz ɑn səm stʃɹɔ.

The sul'dam kicked and tried to throw herself free, but between them, Nynaeve and Min forced her along, down the alley into another, slightly wider passage behind houses, to yet another alley and at last into a rough wooden shed that had apparently once housed two horses, by the stalls. Few could afford to keep horses since the Seanchan came, and in a day of Nynaeve's watching, no one had gone near it. The interior had a musty dustiness that spoke of abandonment. As soon as they were inside, Elayne dropped the silver leash and wiped her hands on some straw.

nɪneɪiv tʃænəld ənʌðɝ tʃɹɪkəl, ən ðə bɹeɪslət fɛl tə ðə dɝt flɔɹ. ðə sʌldəm skwæld ən hɝl hɝsɛlf əbaʊt.

Nynaeve channeled another trickle, and the bracelet fell to the dirt floor. The sul'dam squalled and hurled herself about.

"ɹɛɾi?" nɪneɪiv æskt. ði ʌðɝ tu nɑɾəd, ən ðeɪ jæŋk ðə sækɪŋ ɔf ðɛɹ pɹɪznɝ.

"Ready?" Nynaeve asked. The other two nodded, and they yanked the sacking off their prisoner.

ðə sʌldəm wizd, blu aɪz tɪɹi fɹəm dʌst, bʌɾ əɹ ɹɛd feɪs wɑz ɹɛɾ əz mʌtʃ fɹəm æŋɡɝ əz fɹəm ðə sæk. ʃi dɑɹɾɪd fəɹ ðə dɔɹ, bʌt ðeɪ kɑɾ əɹ ɪn ðə fɝst stɛp. ʃi wɑz nɑt wik, jɛt ðeɪ wɝ θɹi, ən wən ðeɪ wɝ dʌn ðə sʌldəm wɑz stʃɹɪp tə hɝ ʃɪft ən laɪɪŋ ɪn wʌn ə ðə stɔlz, baʊn hæn ən fʊt wɪð staʊt kɔɹd, wɪð ənʌðɝ pis ə kɔɹd tə kip əɹ fɹəm fɔɹsɪŋ ðə ɡæɡ aʊt.

The sul'dam wheezed, blue eyes teary from dust, but her red face was red as much from anger as from the sack. She darted for the door, but they caught her in the first step. She was not weak, yet they were three, and when they were done the sul'dam was stripped to her shift and lying in one of the stalls, bound hand and foot with stout cord, with another piece of cord to keep her from forcing the gag out.

suðɪŋ ə pʌfi lɪp, mɪn aɪd ðə laɪtnɪŋ-pænəl dʒɹɛs ən sɑf buts ðeɪ hæd leɪɾ aʊt. "ɪt maɪt fɪt ju, nɪneɪiv. ɪt woʊn fɪɾ ɪleɪn əɹ mi." ɪleɪn wɑz pɪkɪŋ stʃɹɔ aʊɾ ə hɝ hɛɹ.

Soothing a puffy lip, Min eyed the lightning-paneled dress and soft boots they had laid out. "It might fit you, Nynaeve. It won't fit Elayne or me." Elayne was picking straw out of her hair.

"aɪ kən si ðæt. jə wɝ nɛvɝ ə tʃɔɪs ɛniweɪ, nɑt ɹɪli. ðeɪ noʊ jə tu wɛl." nɪneɪiv hɝidli ɹimuvd əɹ oʊn kloʊðz. ʃi tɔst əm əsaɪɾ ən dɑn ðə sʌldəmz dʒɹɛs. mɪn hɛlpt wɪð ðə bʌɾənz.

"I can see that. You were never a choice anyway, not really. They know you too well." Nynaeve hurriedly removed her own clothes. She tossed them aside and donned the sul'dam's dress. Min helped with the buttons.

nɪneɪiv wɪɡɡəld əɹ toʊz ɪn ðə buts; ðeɪ wɝ ə lɪɾəl taɪt. ðə dʒɹɛs wɑz taɪt, tu, əkɹɔs ðə bʊzəm, ən lus ɛlswɛɹ. ðə hɛm hʌŋ ɔlmoʊs tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, loʊɝ ðən sʌldəm wɔɹ ðɛm, bʌt ðə fɪt wʊɾə bɪn ivən wɝs ɑn ɛni ʌv ði ʌðɝz. snætʃɪŋ ʌp ðə bɹeɪslət, ʃi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ ən kloʊzd ɪɾ ɝaʊn əɹ lɛft ɹɪst. ði ɛnz mɝdʒd, ən ɪt sim sɑləd. ɪt dɪd nɑt fil laɪk ɛniθɪŋ ɪksɛpt ə bɹeɪslət. ʃi hæd bɪn əfɹeɪd ðəɾ ɪt wʊd.

Nynaeve wiggled her toes in the boots; they were a little tight. The dress was tight, too, across the bosom, and loose elsewhere. The hem hung almost to the ground, lower than sul'dam wore them, but the fit would have been even worse on any of the others. Snatching up the bracelet, she took a deep breath and closed it around her left wrist. The ends merged, and it seemed solid. It did not feel like anything except a bracelet. She had been afraid that it would.

"ɡɛt ðə dʒɹɛs, ɪleɪn." ðeɪ hæd daɪɾ ə pɛɹ ə dʒɹɛsəz - wʌn ə hɝz ən wʌn ʌv ɪleɪnz - tə ðə ɡɹeɪ deɪmeɪn wɝ, əɹ əz kloʊs əz ðeɪ kəd mænədʒ, ən hɪɾən əm hɪɹ. ɪleɪn dɪd nɑt muv ɪksɛp tə stɛɹ ət ði oʊpən kɑlɝ ən lɪk əɹ lɪps. "ɪleɪn, juv tə wɛɹ ɪt. tu mɛni ʌv əm əv sin mɪn fəɹ əɹ tə də ɪt. aɪ wʊɾə wɔɹn ɪt, ɪf ðɪs dʒɹɛs hæd fɪt jə ɪnstɛd." ʃi θɔt ʃi wʊɾə ɡɔn mæɾ ɪf ʃi hæd hæd tə wɛɹ ðə kɑlɝ; ðət wɑz waɪ ʃi kəd nɑt meɪk əɹ vɔɪs ʃɑɹp wɪð ɪleɪn naʊ.

"Get the dress, Elayne." They had dyed a pair of dresses - one of hers and one of Elayne's - to the gray damane were, or as close as they could manage, and hidden them here. Elayne did not move except to stare at the open collar and lick her lips. "Elayne, you have to wear it. Too many of them have seen Min for her to do it. I would have worn it, if this dress had fit you instead." She thought she would have gone mad if she had had to wear the collar; that was why she could not make her voice sharp with Elayne now.

"aɪ noʊ." ɪleɪn saɪd. "aɪ dʒʌst wɪʃ aɪ nu mɔɹ ʌv wʌɾ ɪt dʌz tə ju." ʃi dʒɹu hɝ ɹɛd-ɡoʊl hɛɹ aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ. "mɪn, hɛlp mi, pliz." mɪn bɪɡæn ənduɪŋ ðə bʌɾənz daʊn ðə bæk ə hɝ dʒɹɛs.

"I know." Elayne sighed. "I just wish I knew more of what it does to you." She drew her red-gold hair out of the way. "Min, help me, please." Min began undoing the buttons down the back of her dress.

nɪneɪiv mænədʒ tə pɪk ʌp ðə sɪlvɝ kɑlɝ wɪθaʊt flɪntʃɪŋ. "ðɛɹ ɪz wʌn weɪ tə faɪn aʊt." wɪð oʊnli ə moʊmən ə hɛzəteɪʃən, ʃi bɛn ən snæpt ɪɾ ɝaʊn ðə nɛk ə ðə sʌldəm. ʃi dɪzɝvz ɪɾ ɪf ɛniwʌn dʌz, ʃi toʊl hɝsɛlf fɝmli. "ʃi maɪt bi eɪbəl tə tɛl əs sʌmθɪŋ jusfəl, ɛniweɪ." ðə blu-aɪd wʊmən ɡlænst ət ðə liʃ tʃɹeɪlɪŋ fɹəm əɹ nɛk tə nɪneɪivz ɹɪst, ðən ɡlɛɹɾ ʌp əɾ əɹ kəntɛmptʃwəsli.

Nynaeve managed to pick up the silver collar without flinching. "There is one way to find out." With only a moment of hesitation, she bent and snapped it around the neck of the sul'dam. She deserves it if anyone does, she told herself firmly. "She might be able to tell us something useful, anyway." The blue-eyed woman glanced at the leash trailing from her neck to Nynaeve's wrist, then glared up at her contemptuously.

"ɪt dʌznt wɝk ðət weɪ," mɪn sɛd, bʌt nɪneɪiv bɛɹli hɝd.

"It doesn't work that way," Min said, but Nynaeve barely heard.

ʃi wɑz . . . əwɛɹ . . . ʌv ði ʌðɝ wʊmən, əwɛɹ ʌv wʌt ʃi wɑz filɪŋ, kɔɹd dɪɡɪŋ ɪndə hɝ æŋkəlz ən ɪndə hɝ ɹɪsts bɪhaɪn əɹ bæk, ðə ɹæŋk fɪʃ teɪst ə ðə ɹæɡz ɪn əɹ maʊθ, stʃɹɔ pɹɪkɪŋ əɹ θɹu ðə θɪn klɔθ ə hɝ ʃɪft. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ əz ɪf ʃi, nɪneɪiv, fɛl ðiz θɪŋz, bʌɾ ɪn əɹ hɛd wɑz ə lʌmp ə sɛnseɪʃənz ðət ʃi nu bɪlɔŋ tə ðə sʌldəm.

She was . . . aware . . . of the other woman, aware of what she was feeling, cord digging into her ankles and into her wrists behind her back, the rank fish taste of the rags in her mouth, straw pricking her through the thin cloth of her shift. It was not as if she, Nynaeve, felt these things, but in her head was a lump of sensations that she knew belonged to the sul'dam.

ʃi swɑloʊd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɪɡnɔɹ əm - ðeɪ wəd nɑt ɡoʊ əweɪ - ən ədʒɹɛs ðə baʊnd wʊmən. "aɪ woʊn hɝt jə ɪf jə ænsɝ maɪ kwɛstʃənz tʃɹuθfəli. wi ɑɹən sintʃæn. bʌɾ ɪf jə laɪ tə mi. . . ." ʃi lɪftəd ðə liʃ θɹɛɾənɪŋli.

She swallowed, trying to ignore them - they would not go away - and addressed the bound woman. "I won't hurt you if you answer my questions truthfully. We aren't Seanchan. But if you lie to me. . . ." She lifted the leash threateningly.

ðə wʊmənz ʃoʊldɝz ʃʊk, ən əɹ maʊθ kɝld ɝaʊn ðə ɡæɡ ɪn ə snɪɹ. ɪt tʊk nɪneɪiv ə moʊmən tə ɹilaɪz ðə sʌldəm wɑz læfɪŋ.

The woman's shoulders shook, and her mouth curled around the gag in a sneer. It took Nynaeve a moment to realize the sul'dam was laughing.

hɝ maʊθ taɪɾənd, bʌt ðən ə θɔt keɪm tə hɝ. ðət bʌndəl ə sɛnseɪʃən ɪnsaɪɾ əɹ hɛd sim tə bi ɛvɹiθɪŋ fɪzɪkəl ðət ði ʌðɝ wʊmən fɛlt. ɪkspɛɹəmɛntəli, ʃi tʃɹaɪɾ æɾɪŋ tə ɪt.

Her mouth tightened, but then a thought came to her. That bundle of sensation inside her head seemed to be everything physical that the other woman felt. Experimentally, she tried adding to it.

aɪz sʌɾənli bʌlʒɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɝ hɛd, ðə sʌldəm ɡeɪv ə kɹaɪ ðət ðə ɡæɡ oʊnli pɑɹʃəli stɑpt. fænɪŋ əɹ hænz bɪhaɪn əɹ əz ɪf tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə wɔɹɾ ɔf sʌmθɪŋ, ʃi hʌmp θɹu ðə stʃɹɔ ɪn ə veɪn ɛfɝt tə ɪskeɪp.

Eyes suddenly bulging out of her head, the sul'dam gave a cry that the gag only partially stopped. Fanning her hands behind her as if trying to ward off something, she humped through the straw in a vain effort to escape.

nɪneɪiv ɡeɪpt, ən heɪstəli ɹɪd hɝsɛlf ə ði ɛkstʃɹə filɪŋz ʃi hæɾ æɾəd. ðə sʌldəm sæɡd, wipɪŋ.

Nynaeve gaped, and hastily rid herself of the extra feelings she had added. The sul'dam sagged, weeping.

"wʌt. . . . wʌd jə . . . də tə hɝ?" ɪleɪn æsk feɪnli. mɪn oʊnli stɛɹd, hɝ maʊθ hæŋɪŋ oʊpən.

"What. . . . What did you . . . do to her?" Elayne asked faintly. Min only stared, her mouth hanging open.

nɪneɪiv ænsɝd ɡɹʌflaɪ. "ðə seɪm θɪŋ ʃɛɹiəm dɪd tə jə wən jə θɹu ə kʌp ət mɛɹɪθ." laɪt, bʌt ðɪs ɪz ə fɪlθi θɪŋ.

Nynaeve answered gruffly. "The same thing Sheriam did to you when you threw a cup at Marith." Light, but this is a filthy thing.

ɪleɪn ɡʌlp laʊdli. "oʊ."

Elayne gulped loudly. "Oh."

"bʌɾ ən æɾəm ɪzən səpoʊz tə wɝk ðət weɪ," mɪn sɛd. "ðeɪ ɔlweɪz kleɪmd ɪt woʊnt wɝk ɑn ɛni wʊmən u kænɑt tʃænəl."

"But an a'dam isn't supposed to work that way," Min said. "They always claimed it won't work on any woman who cannot channel."

"aɪ də nɑt kɛɹ haʊ ɪts səpoʊz tə wɝk, soʊ lɔŋ əz ɪt dʌz." nɪneɪiv siz ðə sɪlvɝ mɛɾəl liʃ ɹaɪt wɛɹ ɪt dʒɔɪn ðə kɑlɝ, ən pʊl ðə wʊmən ʌp ɪnʌf tə lʊk əɹ ɪn ði aɪz. fɹaɪɾənd aɪz, ʃi sɔ. "ju lɪsən tə mi, ən lɪsən wɛl. aɪ wɑn ænsɝz, ən ɪf aɪ doʊnt ɡɛt ðɛm, əl meɪk jə θɪŋk aɪ hæv hæd ðə haɪɾ ɔf ju." stɑɹk tɛɹɝ ɹoʊld əkɹɔs ðə wʊmənz feɪs, ən nɪneɪivz stʌmək hivd əz ʃi sʌɾənli ɹilaɪz ðə sʌldəm hæd teɪkən əɹ lɪɾɝəli. ɪf ʃi θɪŋks aɪ kæn, ɪts kəz ʃi noʊz. ðəɾ ɪz wʌt ðiz liʃɪz ɑɹ fɔɹ. ʃi tʊk fɝm hoʊld ə hɝsɛlf tə stɑp fɹəm klɔɪŋ ðə bɹeɪsləɾ ɔf əɹ ɹɪst. ɪnstɛd, ʃi hɑɹɾənd əɹ feɪs. "ɑɹ jə ɹɛɾi tə ænsɝ mi? əɹ dʒju nid mɔɹ kənvɪnsɪŋ?"

"I do not care how it is supposed to work, so long as it does." Nynaeve seized the silver metal leash right where it joined the collar, and pulled the woman up enough to look her in the eyes. Frightened eyes, she saw. "You listen to me, and listen well. I want answers, and if I don't get them, I'll make you think I have had the hide off you." Stark terror rolled across the woman's face, and Nynaeve's stomach heaved as she suddenly realized the sul'dam had taken her literally. If she thinks I can, it's because she knows. That is what these leashes are for. She took firm hold of herself to stop from clawing the bracelet off her wrist. Instead, she hardened her face. "Are you ready to answer me? Or do you need more convincing?"

ðə fɹæntɪk hɛd-ʃeɪkɪŋ wɑz ænsɝ ɪnʌf. wən nɪneɪiv ɹimuv ðə ɡæɡ, ðə wʊmən oʊnli pɔz tə swɑloʊ wʌns bɪfɔɹ bæbəlɪŋ, "aɪ wɪl nɑt ɹipɔɹt ju. aɪ swɛɹ ɪt. oʊnli teɪk ðɪs fɹəm maɪ nɛk. aɪ hæv ɡoʊld. teɪk ɪt. aɪ swɛɹ, əl nɛvɝ tɛl ɛniwʌn."

The frantic head-shaking was answer enough. When Nynaeve removed the gag, the woman only paused to swallow once before babbling, "I will not report you. I swear it. Only take this from my neck. I have gold. Take it. I swear, I will never tell anyone."

"bi kwaɪət," nɪneɪiv snæpt, ən ðə wʊmən ʃʌɾ əɹ maʊθ ɪmiɾiətli. "wʌɾ ɪz jəɹ neɪm?"

"Be quiet," Nynaeve snapped, and the woman shut her mouth immediately. "What is your name?"

"sɛɾə. pliz. əl ænsɝ ju, bʌt pliz teɪk - ɪt - ɔf! ɪf ɛniwʌn siz ɪɾ ɑn mi. . . ." sɛɾəz aɪz ɹoʊl daʊn tə stɛɹ ət ðə liʃ, ðən skwizd ʃʌt. "pliz?" ʃi wɪspɝd.

"Seta. Please. I will answer you, but please take - it - off! If anyone sees it on me. . . ." Seta's eyes rolled down to stare at the leash, then squeezed shut. "Please?" she whispered.

nɪneɪiv ɹilaɪz sʌmθɪŋ. ʃi kəd nɛvɝ meɪk ɪleɪn wɛɹ ðət kɑlɝ.

Nynaeve realized something. She could never make Elayne wear that collar.

"bɛst wi ɡɛɾ ɑn wɪð ɪt," ɪleɪn sɛd fɝmli. ʃi wɑz daʊn tə hɝ ʃɪft, tu, naʊ. "ɡɪv mi ə moʊmən tə pʊt ðɪs ʌðɝ dʒɹɛs ɑn, ən - "

"Best we get on with it," Elayne said firmly. She was down to her shift, too, now. "Give me a moment to put this other dress on, and - "

"pʊt jəɹ oʊn kloʊðz bæk ɑn," nɪneɪiv sɛd.

"Put your own clothes back on," Nynaeve said.

"sʌmwʌn əz tə pɹitɛn tə bi ə deɪmeɪn," ɪleɪn sɛd, "ɔɹ wɪl nɛvɝ ɹitʃ ɛɡwin. ðət dʒɹɛs fɪts ju, ən ɪt kænɑt bi mɪn. ðət livz mi."

"Someone has to pretend to be a damane," Elayne said, "or we will never reach Egwene. That dress fits you, and it cannot be Min. That leaves me."

"aɪ sɛd pʊt jəɹ kloʊðz ɑn. wɪv sʌmbɑɾi tə bi əɹ liʃt wʌn." nɪneɪiv tʌɡd ət ðə liʃ ðət hɛl sɛɾə, ən ðə sʌldəm ɡæspt.

"I said put your clothes on. We have somebody to be our Leashed One." Nynaeve tugged at the leash that held Seta, and the sul'dam gasped.

"noʊ! noʊ, pliz! ɪf ɛniwʌn siz mi - " ʃi kʌɾ ɔf ət nɪneɪivz koʊl stɛɹ.

"No! No, please! If anyone sees me - " She cut off at Nynaeve's cold stare.

"æz fɑɹ əz aɪm kənsɝnd, jə ɑɹ wɝs ðən ə mɝɾɝɝ, wɝs ðən ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd. aɪ kæn θɪŋk ʌv ɛniθɪŋ wɝs ðən ju. ðə fæk ðəɾ aɪ hæv tə wɛɹ ðɪs θɪŋ ɑn maɪ ɹɪst, tə bi ðə seɪm əz jə fəɹ ivən ən aʊɝ, sɪkənz mi. soʊ ɪf jə θɪŋk ðəɹ ɪz ɛniθɪŋ əl bɔk ət duɪŋ tə ju, θɪŋk əɡɛn. jə doʊnt wɑnə bi sin? ɡʊd. niðɝ də wi. noʊ wʌn ɹɪli lʊks əɾ ə deɪmeɪn, ðoʊ. əz lɔŋ əz jə kip jəɹ hɛd daʊn ðə weɪ ə liʃt wʌn ɪz səpoʊz tə, noʊ wʌn wɪl ivən noʊɾəs ju. bʌt jə hæd bɛɾɝ də ðə bɛs jə kən tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðə ɹɛst ʌv əs ɑɹənt noʊɾəst, iðɝ. ɪf wi ɑɹ, jə ʃʊɹli wɪl bi sin, ən ɪf ðəɾ ɪz nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə hoʊl ju, aɪ pɹɑməs jə əl meɪk jə kɝs ðə fɝs kɪs jəɹ mʌðɝ ɛvɝ ɡeɪv jəɹ fɑðɝ. də wi ʌndɝstæn itʃ ʌðɝ?"

"As far as I am concerned, you are worse than a murderer, worse than a Darkfriend. I can't think of anything worse than you. The fact that I have to wear this thing on my wrist, to be the same as you for even an hour, sickens me. So if you think there is anything I'll balk at doing to you, think again. You don't want to be seen? Good. Neither do we. No one really looks at a damane, though. As long as you keep your head down the way a Leashed One is supposed to, no one will even notice you. But you had better do the best you can to make sure the rest of us aren't noticed, either. If we are, you surely will be seen, and if that is not enough to hold you, I promise you I'll make you curse the first kiss your mother ever gave your father. Do we understand each other?"

"jɛs," sɛɾə sɛd feɪnli. "aɪ swɛɹ ɪt."

"Yes," Seta said faintly. "I swear it."

nɪneɪiv hæd tə ɹimuv ðə bɹeɪsləɾ ɪn ɔɹɾɝ fəɹ əm tə slaɪɾ ɪleɪnz ɡɹeɪ-daɪd dʒɹɛs daʊn ðə liʃ ən oʊvɝ sɛɾəz hɛd. ɪt dɪd nɑt fɪt ðə wʊmən wɛl, biɪŋ lus ət ðə bʊzəm ən taɪɾ əkɹɔs ðə hɪps, bʌt nɪneɪivz wʊɾə bɪn əz bæd, ən tu ʃɔɹt bɪsaɪdz. nɪneɪiv hoʊpt pipəl ɹɪli dɪd nɑt lʊk ət deɪmeɪn. ʃi pʊt ðə bɹeɪslət bæk ɑn ɹɪlʌktənli.

Nynaeve had to remove the bracelet in order for them to slide Elayne's gray-dyed dress down the leash and over Seta's head. It did not fit the woman well, being loose at the bosom and tight across the hips, but Nynaeve's would have been as bad, and too short besides. Nynaeve hoped people really did not look at damane. She put the bracelet back on reluctantly.

ɪleɪn ɡæðɝɾ ʌp nɪneɪivz kloʊðz, ɹæp ði ʌðɝ daɪd dʒɹɛs ɝaʊn ðɛm, ən meɪɾ ə bʌndəl, ə bʌndəl fəɹ ə wʊmən ɪn fɑɹm kloʊðz tə bi kæɹiɪŋ əz ʃi fɑloʊɾ ə sʌldəm ən ə deɪmeɪn. "ɡɔɪn wɪl iɾ ɪz hɑɹɾ aʊt wən i hɪɹz əbaʊt ðɪs," ʃi sɛd, ən læft. ɪt saʊndəd fɔɹst.

Elayne gathered up Nynaeve's clothes, wrapped the other dyed dress around them, and made a bundle, a bundle for a woman in farm clothes to be carrying as she followed a sul'dam and a damane. "Gawyn will eat his heart out when he hears about this," she said, and laughed. It sounded forced.

nɪneɪiv lʊkt əɾ əɹ kloʊsli, ðən ət mɪn. ɪt wɑz taɪm fəɹ ðə deɪnʒɝəs pɑɹt. "ɑɹ jə ɹɛɾi?"

Nynaeve looked at her closely, then at Min. It was time for the dangerous part. "Are you ready?"

ɪleɪnz smaɪl feɪɾəd. "aɪ æm ɹɛɾi."

Elayne's smile faded. "I am ready."

"ɹɛɾi," mɪn sɛd kɝtli.

"Ready," Min said curtly.

"wɛɹ ɑɹ jə . . . wi . . . ɡoʊɪŋ?" sɛɾə sɛd, kwɪkli æɾɪŋ, "ɪf aɪ meɪ æsk?"

"Where are you . . . we . . . going?" Seta said, quickly adding, "If I may ask?"

"ɪntu ðə laɪənz' dɛn," ɪleɪn toʊl hɝ.

"Into the lions' den," Elayne told her.

"tə dæns wɪð ðə dɑɹk wʌn," mɪn sɛd.

"To dance with the Dark One," Min said.

nɪneɪiv saɪɾ ən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "wʌt ðeɪ ɑɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə seɪ ɪz, wəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ wɛɹ ɔl ðə deɪmeɪn ɑɹ kɛpt, ən wi ɪntɛn tə fɹi wʌn ə ðɛm."

Nynaeve sighed and shook her head. "What they are trying to say is, we are going where all the damane are kept, and we intend to free one of them."

sɛɾə wɑz stɪl ɡeɪpɪŋ ɪn əstɑnɪʃmənt wən ðeɪ hʌsəld əɹ aʊɾ ə ðə ʃɛd.

Seta was still gaping in astonishment when they hustled her out of the shed.

beɪl doʊmən wɑtʃt ðə ɹaɪzɪŋ sʌn fɹəm ðə dɛk ə hɪz ʃɪp. ðə dɑks wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə bʌsəl, ðoʊ ðə stʃɹits liɾɪŋ ʌp fɹəm ðə hɑɹbɝ stʊd lɑɹdʒli ɛmpti. ə ɡʌl pɝtʃt ɑn ə paɪlɪŋ stɛɹɾ ət hɪm; ɡʌlz hæd pɪɾiləs aɪz.

Bayle Domon watched the rising sun from the deck of his ship. The docks were already beginning to bustle, though the streets leading up from the harbor stood largely empty. A gull perched on a piling stared at him; gulls had pitiless eyes.

"ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ əbaʊt ðɪs, kæptən?" jɑɹən æskt. "ɪf ðə sintʃæn wʌndɝ wʌt wɝ ɔl duɪŋ əbɔɹd - "

"Are you sure about this, Captain?" Yarin asked. "If the Seanchan wonder what we're all doing aboard - "

"ju dʒʌs meɪk sɝɾən ðəɹ də bi ən æks nɪɹ ɛvɹi mʊɹɪŋ laɪn," doʊmən sɛd kɝtli. "ænd, jɑɹən? də ɛni mæn tʃɹaɪ tə kʌɾ ə laɪn bɪfɔɹ ðoʊz wɪmən ɑɹ əbɔɹd, əl splɪɾ ɪz skʌl."

"You just make certain there do be an axe near every mooring line," Domon said curtly. "And, Yarin? Do any man try to cut a line before those women are aboard, I will split his skull."

"wʌɾ ɪf ðeɪ doʊn kʌm, kæptən? wʌɾ ɪf ɪts sintʃæn soʊlʒɝz ɪnstɛd?"

"What if they don't come, Captain? What if it's Seanchan soldiers instead?"

"sɛɾəl jəɹ baʊəlz, mæn! ɪf soʊlʒɝz kʌm, əl meɪk ə ɹʌn fəɹ ðə hɑɹbɝ maʊθ, ən ðə laɪɾ əv mɝsi ɑn əs ɔl. bʌɾ əntɪl soʊlʒɝz də kʌm, aɪ min tə weɪt fəɹ ðoʊz wɪmən. naʊ ɡoʊ lʊk əz ɪf jə ɑɹ noʊ duɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ."

"Settle your bowels, man! If soldiers come, I will make a run for the harbor mouth, and the Light have mercy on us all. But until soldiers do come, I mean to wait for those women. Now go look as if you are no doing anything."

doʊmən tɝn bæk tə piɹɪŋ ʌp ɪndə ðə taʊn, təwɔɹd wɛɹ ðə deɪmeɪn wɝ hɛld. hɪz fɪŋɡɝz dʒɹʌmd ə nɝvəs tætu ɑn ðə ɹeɪlɪŋ.

Domon turned back to peering up into the town, toward where the damane were held. His fingers drummed a nervous tattoo on the railing.

ðə bɹiz fɹəm ðə si bɹɔt ðə smɛl ə bɹɛkfəs kʊk faɪɝz tə ɹændz noʊz, ən tʃɹaɪd tə flæp əɾ ɪz mɔθ-iɾən kloʊk, bʌɾ i hɛld ɪt kloʊzd wɪð wʌn hæn əz ɹɛd nɪɹd ðə taʊn. ðəɹ hæd nɑt bɪn ə koʊt tə fɪɾ ɪm ɪn ðə kloʊðz ðeɪ hæd faʊnd, ən i θɔɾ ɪt bɛs tə kip ðə faɪn sɪlvɝ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi ɑn ɪz slivz ən ðə hɛɹənz ɑn ɪz kɑlɝ hɪɾən. ðə sintʃæn æɾətud təwɔɹd kɑŋkɝd pipəl kæɹiɪŋ wɛpənz maɪt nɑɾ ɪkstɛn tə ðoʊz wɪð hɛɹən-mɑɹk sɔɹdz, iðɝ.

The breeze from the sea brought the smell of breakfast cook fires to Rand's nose, and tried to flap at his moth-eaten cloak, but he held it closed with one hand as Red neared the town. There had not been a coat to fit him in the clothes they had found, and he thought it best to keep the fine silver embroidery on his sleeves and the herons on his collar hidden. The Seanchan attitude toward conquered people carrying weapons might not extend to those with heron-mark swords, either.

ðə fɝst ʃædoʊz ə mɔɹnɪŋ stʃɹɛtʃt aʊɾ əhɛɾ ə hɪm. hi kəd dʒʌst si hʊɹɪn ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪn əmʌŋ ðə wæɡən jɑɹdz ən hɔɹs lɑts. oʊnli wʌn əɹ tu mɛn muvd əmʌŋ ðə laɪnz ə mɝtʃənt wæɡənz, ən ðeɪ wɔɹ ðə lɔŋ eɪpɹənz ʌv wilɹaɪts əɹ blæksmɪθs. ɪŋtʃɹ, ðə fɝst ɪn, wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi aʊɾ ə saɪt. pɛɹɪn ən mæt fɑloʊd bɪhaɪn ɹænd ət speɪst ɪntɝvəlz. hi dɪd nɑt lʊk bæk tə tʃɛk ɑn ðɛm. ðəɹ wɑz nɑt səpoʊz tə bi ɛniθɪŋ tə kənɛk ðɛm; faɪv mɛn kʌmɪŋ ɪndə fɑlm əɾ ən ɝli aʊɝ, bʌt nɑt təɡɛðɝ.

The first shadows of morning stretched out ahead of him. He could just see Hurin riding in among the wagon yards and horse lots. Only one or two men moved among the lines of merchant wagons, and they wore the long aprons of wheelwrights or blacksmiths. Ingtar, the first in, was already out of sight. Perrin and Mat followed behind Rand at spaced intervals. He did not look back to check on them. There was not supposed to be anything to connect them; five men coming into Falme at an early hour, but not together.

ðə hɔɹs lɑts sɝaʊndəd hɪm, hɔɹsəz ɔlɹɛɾi kɹaʊɾɪŋ ðə fɛnsəz, weɪɾɪŋ tə bi fɛd. hʊɹɪn pʊɾ ɪz hɛɾ aʊt fɹəm bɪtwin tu steɪbəlz, ðɛɹ dɔɹz stɪl kloʊzd ən bɑɹd, sɔ ɹænd ən moʊʃən tə hɪm bɪfɔɹ dʌkɪŋ bæk. ɹænd tɝn ðə beɪ stæljən ðət weɪ.

The horse lots surrounded him, horses already crowding the fences, waiting to be fed. Hurin put his head out from between two stables, their doors still closed and barred, saw Rand and motioned to him before ducking back. Rand turned the bay stallion that way.

hʊɹɪn stʊd hoʊldɪŋ ɪz hɔɹs baɪ ðə ɹeɪnz. hi hæɾ ɑn wʌn ə ðə lɔŋ vɛsts ɪnstɛɾ ə hɪz koʊt, ən dɪspaɪt ðə hɛvi kloʊk ðət hɪɾ ɪz ʃɔɹt sɔɹɾ ən sɔɹd-bɹeɪkɝ, hi ʃɪvɝd wɪð ðə koʊld. "lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹz bæk ðɛɹ," hi sɛd, nɑɾɪŋ daʊn ðə nɛɹoʊ pæsədʒ. "hi sɛz wɪl liv ðə hɔɹsəz hɪɹ ən ɡoʊ ðə ɹɛst ə ðə weɪ ɑn fʊt." əz ɹænd dɪsmaʊntɪd, ðə snɪfɝ æɾəd, "feɪn wɛn ɹaɪt daʊn ðət stʃɹit, lɔɹd ɹænd. aɪ kən ɔlmoʊst smɛl ɪt fɹəm hɪɹ."

Hurin stood holding his horse by the reins. He had on one of the long vests instead of his coat, and despite the heavy cloak that hid his short sword and sword-breaker, he shivered with the cold. "Lord Ingtar's back there," he said, nodding down the narrow passage. "He says we'll leave the horses here and go the rest of the way on foot." As Rand dismounted, the sniffer added, "Fain went right down that street, Lord Rand. I can almost smell it from here."

ɹænd lɛd ɹɛd daʊn ðə weɪ tə wɛɹ ɪŋtʃɹ hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi taɪɾ ɪz oʊn hɔɹs bɪhaɪn ðə steɪbəl. ðə ʃaɪnɝən dɪd nɑt lʊk vɛɹi mʌtʃ ə lɔɹɾ ɪn ə dɝɾi flis koʊt wɪð hoʊlz wɔɹn θɹu ðə lɛðɝ ɪn sɛvɹəl pleɪsəz, ən ɪz sɔɹd lʊkt ɑd bɛltəɾ oʊvɝ ɪt. hɪz aɪz hæɾ ə fivɝɪʃ ɪntɛnsəɾi.

Rand led Red down the way to where Ingtar had already tied his own horse behind the stable. The Shienaran did not look very much a lord in a dirty fleece coat with holes worn through the leather in several places, and his sword looked odd belted over it. His eyes had a feverish intensity.

taɪɪŋ ɹɛɾ əlɔŋsaɪɾ ɪŋtʃɹz stæljən, ɹænd hɛzɪteɪɾɪd oʊvɝ ɪz sæɾəlbæɡz. hi hæd nɑt bɪn eɪbəl tə liv ðə bænɝ bɪhaɪnd. hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ɛni ʌv ðə soʊlʒɝz wʊɾə ɡɔn ɪndə ðə bæɡz, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt seɪ ðə seɪm fəɹ vɛɹɪn, nɔɹ pɹɪdɪkt wʌt ʃi wəd də ɪf ʃi faʊn ðə bænɝ. stɪl, ɪt meɪɾ ɪm ənizi tə hæv ɪt wɪð hɪm. hi dɪsaɪɾɪd tə liv ðə sæɾəlbæɡz taɪd bɪhaɪn ɪz sæɾəl.

Tying Red alongside Ingtar's stallion, Rand hesitated over his saddlebags. He had not been able to leave the banner behind. He did not think any of the soldiers would have gone into the bags, but he could not say the same for Verin, nor predict what she would do if she found the banner. Still, it made him uneasy to have it with him. He decided to leave the saddlebags tied behind his saddle.

mæt dʒɔɪn ðɛm, ən ə fju moʊməns leɪɾɝ hʊɹɪn keɪm wɪð pɛɹɪn. mæt wɔɹ bæɡi tʃɹaʊzɝz stʌft ɪndə ðə tɑps ə hɪz buts, ən pɛɹɪn ɪz tu-ʃɔɹt kloʊk. ɹænd θɔt ðeɪ ɔl lʊk laɪk vɪlənəs bɛɡɝz, bʌt ðeɪ hæɾ ɔl pæs lɑɹdʒli ənnoʊɾɪst ɪn ðə vɪlədʒəz.

Mat joined them, and a few moments later Hurin came with Perrin. Mat wore baggy trousers stuffed into the tops of his boots, and Perrin his too-short cloak. Rand thought they all looked like villainous beggars, but they had all passed largely unnoticed in the villages.

"naʊ," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd. "lɛɾ əs si wʌt wi si."

"Now," Ingtar said. "Let us see what we see."

ðeɪ stʃɹoʊld aʊt tə ðə dɝt stʃɹiɾ əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd noʊ pɝtɪkjəlɝ dɛstəneɪʃən ɪn maɪnd, tɔkɪŋ əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz, ən æmbəl pæs ðə wæɡən jɑɹdz ɑntu sloʊpɪŋ kɑbəlstoʊn stʃɹits. ɹænd wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ wʌɾ i hɪmsɛlf sɛd, mʌtʃ lɛs ɛniwʌn ɛls. ɪŋtʃɹz plæn hæd bɪn fəɹ əm tə lʊk laɪk ɛni ʌðɝ ɡɹup ə mɛn wɔkɪŋ təɡɛðɝ, bʌt ðəɹ wɝ ɔl tu fju pipəl aʊt-ʌv-dɔɹz. faɪv mɛn meɪɾ ə kɹaʊɾ ɑn ðoʊz koʊl mɔɹnɪŋ stʃɹits.

They strolled out to the dirt street as if they had no particular destination in mind, talking among themselves, and ambled past the wagon yards onto sloping cobblestone streets. Rand was not sure what he himself said, much less anyone else. Ingtar's plan had been for them to look like any other group of men walking together, but there were all too few people out-of-doors. Five men made a crowd on those cold morning streets.

ðeɪ wɔkt ɪn ə bʌntʃ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz hʊɹɪn u lɛd ðɛm, snɪfɪŋ ði ɛɹ ən tɝnɪŋ ʌp ðɪs stʃɹiɾ ən daʊn ðæt. ðə ɹɛs tɝnd wən i dɪd, əz ɪf ðət wɑz wʌt ðeɪ hæɾ ɪntɛndəɾ ɔl əlɔŋ. "hiz kɹɪskɹɔs ðɪs taʊn," hʊɹɪn mʌɾɝd, ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ. "hɪz smɛl ɪz ɛvɹiwɛɹ, ən ɪt stɪŋks soʊ, ɪts hɑɹd tə tɛl oʊl fɹəm nu. ət list aɪ noʊ hiz stɪl hɪɹ. səm ʌv ɪt kænɑt bi oʊldɝ ðən ə deɪ əɹ tu, ɪm ʃʊɹ. aɪm ʃʊɹ," hi æɾəd lɛs daʊtfəli.

They walked in a bunch, but it was Hurin who led them, sniffing the air and turning up this street and down that. The rest turned when he did, as if that was what they had intended all along. "He's crisscrossed this town," Hurin muttered, grimacing. "His smell is everywhere, and it stinks so, it's hard to tell old from new. At least I know he's still here. Some of it cannot be older than a day or two, I'm sure. I am sure," he added less doubtfully.

ə fju mɔɹ pipəl bɪɡæn tə əpɪɹ, hɪɹ ə fɹut pɛdlɝ sɛɾɪŋ ɪz wɛɹz ɑn teɪbəlz, ðəɹ ə fɛloʊ hɝiɪŋ əlɔŋ wɪð ə bɪɡ ɹoʊl ə pɑɹtʃməns ʌndɝ ɪz ɑɹm ən ə skɛtʃ-bɔɹd slʌŋ əkɹɔs ɪz bæk, ə naɪf-ʃɑɹpənɝ ɔɪlɪŋ ðə ʃæft ə hɪz ɡɹaɪndɪŋ wil ɑn ɪts bæɹoʊ. tu wɪmən wɔk baɪ, hɛɾəd ði ʌðɝ weɪ, wʌn wɪð daʊnkæst aɪz ən ə sɪlvɝ kɑlɝ ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk, ði ʌðɝ, ɪn ə dʒɹɛs wɝkt wɪð laɪtnɪŋ boʊls, hoʊldɪŋ ə kɔɪl sɪlvɝ liʃ.

A few more people began to appear, here a fruit peddler setting his wares on tables, there a fellow hurrying along with a big roll of parchments under his arm and a sketch-board slung across his back, a knife-sharpener oiling the shaft of his grinding wheel on its barrow. Two women walked by, headed the other way, one with downcast eyes and a silver collar around her neck, the other, in a dress worked with lightning bolts, holding a coiled silver leash.

ɹændz bɹɛθ kɑt; ɪt wɑz ən ɛfɝt nɑt tə lʊk bæk ət ðɛm.

Rand's breath caught; it was an effort not to look back at them.

"wɑz ðət . . . ?" mæts aɪz wɝ oʊpən waɪd, stɛɹɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə hɑloʊz ə hɪz aɪ sɑkəts. "wɑz ðəɾ ə deɪmeɪn?"

"Was that . . . ?" Mat's eyes were open wide, staring out of the hollows of his eye sockets. "Was that a damane?"

"ðæɾ ɪz ðə weɪ ðeɪ wɝ dɪskɹaɪbd," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd kɝtli. "hʊɹɪn, ɑɹ wi gɑnə wɔk ɛvɹi stʃɹiɾ ɪn ðɪs ʃædoʊ-kɝs taʊn?"

"That is the way they were described," Ingtar said curtly. "Hurin, are we going to walk every street in this Shadow-cursed town?"

"hiz bɪn ɛvɹiwɛɹ, lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹ," hʊɹɪn sɛd. "hɪz stɛntʃ ɪz ɛvɹiwɛɹ." ðeɪ hæd kʌm ɪndə ən ɛɹiə wɛɹ ðə stoʊn haʊsəz wɝ θɹi ən fɔɹ stɔɹiz haɪ, əz bɪɡ əz ɪnz.

"He's been everywhere, Lord Ingtar," Hurin said. "His stench is everywhere." They had come into an area where the stone houses were three and four stories high, as big as inns.

ðeɪ ɹaʊndəɾ ə kɔɹnɝ, ən ɹænd wɑz teɪkən əbæk baɪ ðə saɪɾ ʌv ə skɔɹ ə sintʃæn soʊlʒɝz stændɪŋ ɡɑɹɾ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ə bɪɡ haʊs ɑn wʌn saɪɾ ə ðə stʃɹit - ən baɪ ðə saɪɾ ə tu wɪmən ɪn laɪtnɪŋ-mɑɹk dʒɹɛsəz tɔkɪŋ ɑn ðə dɔɹstɛps ʌv ənʌðɝ əkɹɔs fɹəm ɪt. ə bænɝ flæpt ɪn ðə wɪn oʊvɝ ðə haʊs ðə soʊlʒɝz pɹətɛktəd; ə ɡoʊldən hɔk klʌtʃɪŋ laɪtnɪŋ boʊls. nʌθɪŋ mɑɹkt aʊt ðə haʊs wɛɹ ðə wɪmən tɔkt ɪksɛp ðɛmsɛlvz. ði ɔfəsɝz ɑɹmɝ wɑz ɹisplɛndən ɪn ɹɛɾ ən blæk ən ɡoʊld, hɪz hɛlmət ɡɪldɪɾ ən peɪntəd tə lʊk laɪk ə spaɪɾɝz hɛd. ðən ɹænd sɔ ðə tu bɪɡ, lɛðɝi-skɪnd ʃeɪps kɹaʊtʃt əmʌŋ ðə soʊlʒɝz ən mɪst ə stɛp.

They rounded a corner, and Rand was taken aback by the sight of a score of Seanchan soldiers standing guard in front of a big house on one side of the street - and by the sight of two women in lightning-marked dresses talking on the doorsteps of another across from it. A banner flapped in the wind over the house the soldiers protected; a golden hawk clutching lightning bolts. Nothing marked out the house where the women talked except themselves. The officer's armor was resplendent in red and black and gold, his helmet gilded and painted to look like a spider's head. Then Rand saw the two big, leathery-skinned shapes crouched among the soldiers and missed a step.

ɡɹoʊm. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ mɪsteɪkɪŋ ðoʊz wɛdʒ-ʃeɪp hɛdz wɪð ðɛɹ θɹi aɪz. ðeɪ kæn bi. pɝhæps i wɑz ɹɪli əslip, ən ðɪs wɑz ɔl ə naɪtmɛɹ. meɪbi wi hævən ivən lɛft fəɹ fɑlm, jɛt.

Grolm. There was no mistaking those wedge-shaped heads with their three eyes. They can't be. Perhaps he was really asleep, and this was all a nightmare. Maybe we haven't even left for Falme, yet.

ði ʌðɝz stɛɹɾ ət ðə bists əz ðeɪ wɔk pæs ðə ɡɑɹɾəd haʊs.

The others stared at the beasts as they walked past the guarded house.

"wʌɾ ɪn ðə neɪm ə ðə laɪɾ ɑɹ ðeɪ?" mæt æskt.

"What in the name of the Light are they?" Mat asked.

hʊɹɪnz aɪz simd əz bɪɡ əz ɪz feɪs. "lɔɹd ɹænd, ðeɪɹ. . . . ðoʊz ɑɹ. . . ."

Hurin's eyes seemed as big as his face. "Lord Rand, they're. . . . Those are. . . ."

"ɪt dʌzn mæɾɝ," ɹænd sɛd. æftɝ ə moʊmənt, hʊɹɪn nɑɾəd.

"It doesn't matter," Rand said. After a moment, Hurin nodded.

"wi ɑɹ hɪɹ fəɹ ðə hɔɹn," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd, "nɑt tə stɛɹ ət sintʃæn mɑnstɝz. kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾ ɑn faɪndɪŋ feɪn, hʊɹɪn."

"We are here for the Horn," Ingtar said, "not to stare at Seanchan monsters. Concentrate on finding Fain, Hurin."

ðə soʊlʒɝz bɛɹli ɡlænst ət ðɛm. ðə stʃɹit ɹæn stʃɹeɪt daʊn tə ðə ɹaʊn hɑɹbɝ. ɹænd kəd si ʃɪps æŋkɝd daʊn ðɛɹ; tɔl, skwɛɹ-lʊkɪŋ ʃɪps wɪð haɪ mæsts, smɔl ɪn ðət dɪstəns.

The soldiers barely glanced at them. The street ran straight down to the round harbor. Rand could see ships anchored down there; tall, square-looking ships with high masts, small in that distance.

"hiz bɪn hɪɹ ə lɑt." hʊɹɪn skɹʌbd əɾ ɪz noʊz wɪð ðə bæk ə hɪz hænd. "ðə stʃɹit stɪŋks ə leɪɝ ɑn leɪɝ ɑn leɪɝ ə hɪm. aɪ θɪŋk i maɪɾ əv bɪn hɪɹ əz leɪɾ əz jɛstɝdeɪ, lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹ. meɪbi læs naɪt."

"He's been here a lot." Hurin scrubbed at his nose with the back of his hand. "The street stinks of layer on layer on layer of him. I think he might have been here as late as yesterday, Lord Ingtar. Maybe last night."

mæt sʌɾənli klʌtʃt ɪz koʊt wɪð boʊθ hænz. "ɪts ɪn ðɛɹ," hi wɪspɝd. hi tɝn ɝaʊn ən wɔk bækwɝdz, piɹɪŋ ət ðə tɔl haʊs wɪð ðə bænɝ. "ðə dæɡɝ ɪz ɪn ðɛɹ. aɪ dɪdn ivən noʊɾəs ɪt bɪfɔɹ, kəz ə ðoʊz - ðoʊz θɪŋz, bʌɾ aɪ kən fil ɪt."

Mat suddenly clutched his coat with both hands. "It's in there," he whispered. He turned around and walked backwards, peering at the tall house with the banner. "The dagger is in there. I didn't even notice it before, because of those - those things, but I can feel it."

pɛɹɪn poʊkt ə fɪŋɡɝ ɪn ɪz ɹɪbz. "wɛl, stɑp ðət bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ stɑɹt wʌndɝɪŋ waɪ jəɹ ɡɑəlɪŋ əɾ əm laɪk ə ful."

Perrin poked a finger in his ribs. "Well, stop that before they start wondering why you're goggling at them like a fool."

ɹænd ɡlænst oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. ði ɔfəsɝ wɑz lʊkɪŋ æftɝ ðɛm.

Rand glanced over his shoulder. The officer was looking after them.

mæt tɝn bæk ɝaʊn sʌlənli. "ɑɹ wi dʒʌs gɑnə kip ɑn wɔkɪŋ? ɪts ɪn ðɛɹ, aɪ tɛl ju."

Mat turned back around sullenly. "Are we just going to keep on walking? It's in there, I tell you."

"ðə hɔɹn ɪz wʌt wəɹ æftɝ," ɪŋtʃɹ ɡɹaʊld. "aɪ min tə faɪn feɪn ən meɪk ɪm tɛl mi wɛɹ ɪɾ ɪz." hi dɪd nɑt sloʊ daʊn.

"The Horn is what we are after," Ingtar growled. "I mean to find Fain and make him tell me where it is." He did not slow down.

mæt sɛd nʌθɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪz ɪntaɪɝ feɪs wɑz ə pli.

Mat said nothing, but his entire face was a plea.

aɪ hæv tə faɪn feɪn, tu, ɹænd θɔt. aɪ hæv tə. bʌt wən i lʊkt ət mæts feɪs, hi sɛd, "ɪŋtʃɹ, ɪf ðə dæɡɝ ɪz ɪn ðət haʊs, feɪn laɪkli ɪz, tu. aɪ kæn si hɪm lɛɾɪŋ ðə dæɡɝ əɹ ðə hɔɹn, iðɝ wʌn, fɑɹ aʊɾ ə hɪz saɪt."

I have to find Fain, too, Rand thought. I have to. But when he looked at Mat's face, he said, "Ingtar, if the dagger is in that house, Fain likely is, too. I can't see him letting the dagger or the Horn, either one, far out of his sight."

ɪŋtʃɹ stɑpt. æftɝ ə moʊmənt, hi sɛd, "ɪt kəd bi, bʌt wɪl nɛvɝ noʊ fɹəm aʊt hɪɹ."

Ingtar stopped. After a moment, he said, "It could be, but we will never know from out here."

"wi kəd wɑtʃ fəɹ ɪm tə kʌm aʊt," ɹænd sɛd. "ɪf i kʌmz aʊɾ ət ðɪs taɪm ə ðə mɔɹnɪŋ, ðən i spɛn ðə naɪt ðɛɹ. ən əl weɪdʒɝ wɛɹ i slips ɪz wɛɹ ðə hɔɹn ɪz. ɪf i dʌz kʌm aʊt, wi kən bi bæk tə vɛɹɪn baɪ mɪddeɪ ən əv ə plæn meɪd bɪfɔɹ naɪtfɔl."

"We could watch for him to come out," Rand said. "If he comes out at this time of the morning, then he spent the night there. And I'll wager where he sleeps is where the Horn is. If he does come out, we can be back to Verin by midday and have a plan made before nightfall."

"aɪ də nɑt min tə weɪt fəɹ vɛɹɪn," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd, "ænd niðɝ wɪl aɪ weɪt fəɹ naɪt. aɪv weɪɾəd tu lɔŋ ɔlɹɛɾi. aɪ min tə hæv ðə hɔɹn ɪn maɪ hænz bɪfɔɹ ðə sʌn sɛts əɡɛn."

"I do not mean to wait for Verin," Ingtar said, "and neither will I wait for night. I've waited too long already. I mean to have the Horn in my hands before the sun sets again."

"bʌt wi doʊnt noʊ, ɪŋtʃɹ."

"But we don't know, Ingtar."

"aɪ noʊ ðə dæɡɝ ɪz ɪn ðɛɹ," mæt sɛd.

"I know the dagger is in there," Mat said.

"æn hʊɹɪn sɛz feɪn wɑz hɪɹ læs naɪt." ɪŋtʃɹ oʊvɝɹoʊd hʊɹɪnz ətɛmps tə kwɑləfaɪ ðæt. "ɪɾ ɪz ðə fɝs taɪm juv bɪn wɪlɪŋ tə seɪ ɛniθɪŋ kloʊsɝ ðən ə deɪ əɹ tu. wəɹ gɑnə teɪk bæk ðə hɔɹn naʊ. naʊ!"

"And Hurin says Fain was here last night." Ingtar overrode Hurin's attempts to qualify that. "It is the first time you have been willing to say anything closer than a day or two. We are going to take back the Horn now. Now!"

"haʊ?" ɹænd sɛd. ði ɔfəsɝ wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ wɑtʃɪŋ ðɛm, bʌt ðəɹ wɝ stɪl ət lis twɛnti soʊlʒɝz ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə bɪldɪŋ. ən ə pɛɹ ʌv ɡɹoʊm. ðɪs ɪz mædnəs. ðəɹ kæn bi ɡɹoʊm hɪɹ. θɪŋkɪŋ ɪt dɪd nɑt meɪk ðə bists dɪsəpɪɹ, ðoʊ.

"How?" Rand said. The officer was no longer watching them, but there were still at least twenty soldiers in front of the building. And a pair of grolm. This is madness. There can't be grolm here. Thinking it did not make the beasts disappear, though.

"ðɛɹ sim tə bi ɡɑɹɾənz bɪhaɪn ɔl ðiz haʊsəz," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd, lʊkɪŋ ɝaʊn θɔtfəli. "ɪf wʌn ə ðoʊz æliz ɹʌnz baɪ ə ɡɑɹɾən wɔl. . . . səmtaɪmz mɛn ɑɹ soʊ bɪzi ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðɛɹ fɹʌnt, ðeɪ nəɡlɛk ðɛɹ bæk. kʌm." hi hɛɾəd stʃɹeɪt fəɹ ðə nɪɹəs nɛɹoʊ pæsədʒ bɪtwin tu ʌv ðə tɔl haʊsəz. hʊɹɪn ən mæt tʃɹɑɾəd ɹaɪɾ æftɝ hɪm.

"There seem to be gardens behind all these houses," Ingtar said, looking around thoughtfully. "If one of those alleys runs by a garden wall. . . . Sometimes men are so busy guarding their front, they neglect their back. Come." He headed straight for the nearest narrow passage between two of the tall houses. Hurin and Mat trotted right after him.

ɹænd ɪkstʃeɪnʒd lʊks wɪð pɛɹɪn - hɪz kɝli-hɛɹd fɹɛnd ɡeɪv ə ɹɪzaɪnd ʃɹʌɡ - ən ðeɪ fɑloʊd, tu.

Rand exchanged looks with Perrin - his curly-haired friend gave a resigned shrug - and they followed, too.

ði æli wɑz bɛɹli waɪɾɝ ðən ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz, bʌɾ ɪt ɹæn bɪtwin haɪ ɡɑɹɾən wɔlz əntɪl ɪt kɹɔst ənʌðɝ æli bɪɡ ɪnʌf fəɹ ə pʊʃbæɹoʊ əɹ smɔl kɑɹt. ðət wɑz kɑbəlstoʊnd, tu, bʌɾ oʊnli ðə bæks ə bɪldɪŋz lʊk daʊn ɑn ɪt, ʃʌɾɝd wɪndoʊz ən ɪkspænsɪz ə stoʊn, ən ðə haɪ bæk wɔlz ʌv ɡɑɹɾənz oʊvɝtɑp baɪ nɪɹli lifləs bɹæntʃəz.

The alley was barely wider than their shoulders, but it ran between high garden walls until it crossed another alley big enough for a pushbarrow or small cart. That was cobblestoned, too, but only the backs of buildings looked down on it, shuttered windows and expanses of stone, and the high back walls of gardens overtopped by nearly leafless branches.

ɪŋtʃɹ lɛɾ əm əlɔŋ ðəɾ æli əntɪl ðeɪ wɝ ɑpəzət ðə weɪvɪŋ bænɝ. teɪkɪŋ ɪz stil-bækt ɡɔnləts fɹəm ʌndɝ ɪz koʊt, hi pʊɾ əm ɑn ən lɛpt ʌp tə kætʃ ðə tɑp ə ðə wɔl, ðən pʊl hɪmsɛlf ʌp ɪnʌf tə pik oʊvɝ. hi ɹipɔɹɾəd ɪn ə loʊ mɑnətoʊn. "tʃɹiz. flaʊɝ bɛdz. wɔks. ðəɹ ɪzən ə soʊl tə bi - weɪt! ə ɡɑɹd. wʌn mæn. hi ɪzən ivən wɛɹɪŋ ɪz hɛlmət. kaʊn tə fɪfti, ðən fɑloʊ mi." hi swʌŋ ə but tə ðə tɑp ə ðə wɔl ən ɹoʊld oʊvɝ ɪnsaɪd, dɪsəpɪɹɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ɹænd kəd seɪ ə wɝd.

Ingtar led them along that alley until they were opposite the waving banner. Taking his steel-backed gauntlets from under his coat, he put them on and leaped up to catch the top of the wall, then pulled himself up enough to peek over. He reported in a low monotone. "Trees. Flower beds. Walks. There isn't a soul to be - Wait! A guard. One man. He isn't even wearing his helmet. Count to fifty, then follow me." He swung a boot to the top of the wall and rolled over inside, disappearing before Rand could say a word.

mæt bɪɡæn tə kaʊn sloʊli. ɹænd hɛld ɪz bɹɛθ. pɛɹɪn fɪŋɡɝɾ ɪz æks, ən hʊɹɪn ɡɹɪp ðə hɪls ə hɪz wɛpənz.

Mat began to count slowly. Rand held his breath. Perrin fingered his axe, and Hurin gripped the hilts of his weapons.

". . . fɪfti." hʊɹɪn skɹæmbəld ʌp ən oʊvɝ ðə wɔl bɪfɔɹ ðə wɝd wɑz wɛl aʊɾ ə mæts maʊθ. pɛɹɪn wɛn ɹaɪt bɪsaɪd hɪm.

". . . fifty." Hurin scrambled up and over the wall before the word was well out of Mat's mouth. Perrin went right beside him.

ɹænd θɔt mæt maɪt nid səm hɛlp - hi lʊk soʊ peɪl ən dʒɹɔn - bʌɾ i ɡeɪv noʊ saɪn ʌv ɪɾ əz i skɹæmbəld ʌp. ðə stoʊn wɔl pɹəvaɪɾəd plɛnti ʌv hændhoʊlz, ən moʊməns leɪɾɝ ɹænd wɑz kɹaʊtʃt ɑn ði ɪnsaɪd wɪð mæt ən pɛɹɪn ən hʊɹɪn.

Rand thought Mat might need some help - he looked so pale and drawn - but he gave no sign of it as he scrambled up. The stone wall provided plenty of handholds, and moments later Rand was crouched on the inside with Mat and Perrin and Hurin.

ðə ɡɑɹɾən wɑz ɪn ðə ɡɹɪp ə dip ɔɾəm, flaʊɝ bɛdz ɛmpti ɪksɛp fəɹ ə fju ɛvɝɡɹin ʃɹʌbz, tʃɹi bɹæntʃəz nɪɹli bɛɹ. ðə wɪn ðət ɹɪpəl ðə bænɝ stɝd dʌst əkɹɔs ðə flæɡstoʊn wɔks. fəɹ ə moʊmən ɹænd kəd nɑt faɪn ɪŋtʃɹ. ðən i sɔ ðə ʃaɪnɝən, flæɾ əɡɛns ðə bæk wɔl ə ðə haʊs, moʊʃənɪŋ əm ɑn wɪð sɔɹɾ ɪn hænd.

The garden was in the grip of deep autumn, flower beds empty except for a few evergreen shrubs, tree branches nearly bare. The wind that rippled the banner stirred dust across the flagstone walks. For a moment Rand could not find Ingtar. Then he saw the Shienaran, flat against the back wall of the house, motioning them on with sword in hand.

ɹænd ɹæn ɪn ə kɹaʊtʃ, mɔɹ kɑnʃəs ə ðə wɪndoʊz blæŋkli piɹɪŋ daʊn fɹəm ðə haʊs ðən ə hɪz fɹɛnz ɹʌnɪŋ bɪsaɪd hɪm. ɪt wɑz ə ɹɪlif tə pɹɛs hɪmsɛlf əɡɛns ðə haʊs bɪsaɪɾ ɪŋtʃɹ.

Rand ran in a crouch, more conscious of the windows blankly peering down from the house than of his friends running beside him. It was a relief to press himself against the house beside Ingtar.

mæt kɛp mʌɾɝɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf, "ɪts ɪn ðɛɹ. aɪ kən fil ɪt."

Mat kept muttering to himself, "It's in there. I can feel it."

"wɛɹ ɪz ðə ɡɑɹd?" ɹænd wɪspɝd.

"Where is the guard?" Rand whispered.

"dɛd," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd. "ðə mæn wɑz oʊvɝkɑnfɪɾənt. hi nɛvɝ ivən tʃɹaɪd tə ɹeɪz ə kɹaɪ. aɪ hɪɾ ɪz bɑɾi ʌndɝ wʌn ə ðoʊz bʊʃəz."

"Dead," Ingtar said. "The man was overconfident. He never even tried to raise a cry. I hid his body under one of those bushes."

ɹænd stɛɹɾ ət hɪm. ðə sintʃæn wɑz oʊvɝkɑnfɪɾənt? ði oʊnli θɪŋ ðət kɛpt ɪm fɹəm ɡoʊɪŋ bæk ɹaɪt ðən wɑz mæts æŋɡwɪʃt mɝmɝz.

Rand stared at him. The Seanchan was overconfident? The only thing that kept him from going back right then was Mat's anguished murmurs.

"wi ɑɹ ɔlmoʊs ðɛɹ." ɪŋtʃɹ saʊndəɾ əz ɪf i wɝ spikɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf, tu. "ɔlmoʊs ðɛɹ. kʌm."

"We are almost there." Ingtar sounded as if he were speaking to himself, too. "Almost there. Come."

ɹænd dʒɹu hɪz sɔɹɾ əz ðeɪ stɑɹɾəd ʌp ðə bæk stɛps. hi wɑz əwɛɹ ə hʊɹɪn ənlɪmbɝɪŋ ɪz ʃɔɹt-bleɪɾɪd sɔɹɾ ən nɑtʃt sɔɹd-bɹeɪkɝ, ən pɛɹɪn ɹɪlʌktənli dʒɹɔɪŋ ɪz æks fɹəm ðə lup ɑn ɪz bɛlt.

Rand drew his sword as they started up the back steps. He was aware of Hurin unlimbering his short-bladed sword and notched sword-breaker, and Perrin reluctantly drawing his axe from the loop on his belt.

ðə hɔlweɪ ɪnsaɪd wɑz nɛɹoʊ. ə hæf-oʊpən dɔɹ tə ðɛɹ ɹaɪt smɛld laɪk ə kɪtʃən. sɛvɹəl pipəl wɝ muvɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪn ðət ɹum; ðəɹ wɑz ən ɪndɪstɪŋɡwɪʃəbəl saʊn ə vɔɪsəz, ən əkeɪʒənəli ðə sɑf klæɾɝ ʌv ə pɑt lɪd.

The hallway inside was narrow. A half-open door to their right smelled like a kitchen. Several people were moving about in that room; there was an indistinguishable sound of voices, and occasionally the soft clatter of a pot lid.

ɪŋtʃɹ moʊʃən mæt tə lid, ən ðeɪ kɹɛp baɪ ðə dɔɹ. ɹænd wɑtʃt ðə nɛɹoʊɪŋ oʊpənɪŋ əntɪl ðeɪ wɝ ɝaʊn ðə nɛks kɔɹnɝ.

Ingtar motioned Mat to lead, and they crept by the door. Rand watched the narrowing opening until they were around the next corner.

ə slɛndɝ jʌŋ wʊmən wɪð dɑɹk hɛɹ keɪm aʊɾ ʌv ə dɔɹ əhɛɾ ə ðɛm, kæɹiɪŋ ə tʃɹeɪ wɪð wʌn kʌp. ðeɪ ɔl fɹoʊz. ʃi tɝn ði ʌðɝ weɪ wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ ɪn ðɛɹ dɝɛkʃən. ɹændz aɪz waɪɾənd. hɝ lɔŋ waɪt ɹoʊb wɑz ɔl bʌt tʃɹænspɛɹənt. ʃi vænɪʃt ɝaʊn ənʌðɝ kɔɹnɝ.

A slender young woman with dark hair came out of a door ahead of them, carrying a tray with one cup. They all froze. She turned the other way without looking in their direction. Rand's eyes widened. Her long white robe was all but transparent. She vanished around another corner.

"dɪd jə si ðæt?" mæt sɛd hɔɹsli. "ju kəd si ɹaɪt θɹu - "

"Did you see that?" Mat said hoarsely. "You could see right through - "

ɪŋtʃɹ klæpt ə hæn oʊvɝ mæts maʊθ ən wɪspɝd, "kip jəɹ maɪn ɑn waɪ wəɹ hɪɹ. naʊ faɪn ɪt. faɪn ðə hɔɹn fəɹ mi."

Ingtar clapped a hand over Mat's mouth and whispered, "Keep your mind on why we are here. Now find it. Find the Horn for me."

mæt pɔɪntəd tə ə nɛɹoʊ sɛɾ ʌv waɪndɪŋ stɛɹz. ðeɪ klaɪmd ə flaɪt, ən i lɛɾ əm təwɔɹd ðə fɹʌn ə ðə haʊs. ðə fɝnɪʃɪŋz ɪn ðə hɔlweɪz wɝ spɑɹs, ən simd ɔl kɝvz. hɪɹ ən ðəɹ ə tæpəstʃɹi hʌŋ ɑn ə wɔl, əɹ ə foʊldɪŋ skɹin stʊɾ əɡɛnst ɪt, itʃ peɪntəd wɪð ə fju bɝdz ɑn bɹæntʃəz, əɹ ə flaʊɝ əɹ tu. ə ɹɪvɝ floʊɾ əkɹɔs wʌn skɹin, bʌɾ əsaɪd fɹəm ɹɪpəlɪŋ wɔɾɝ ən nɛɹoʊ stʃɹɪps ə ɹɪvɝbæŋk, ðə ɹɛst ʌv ɪt wɑz blæŋk.

Mat pointed to a narrow set of winding stairs. They climbed a flight, and he led them toward the front of the house. The furnishings in the hallways were sparse, and seemed all curves. Here and there a tapestry hung on a wall, or a folding screen stood against it, each painted with a few birds on branches, or a flower or two. A river flowed across one screen, but aside from rippling water and narrow strips of riverbank, the rest of it was blank.

ɔl ɝaʊn əm ɹænd kəd hɪɹ ðə saʊnz ə pipəl stɝɪŋ, slɪpɝz skʌfɪŋ ɑn ðə flɔɹ, sɑf mɝmɝz ə spitʃ. hi dɪd nɑt si ɛniwʌn, bʌɾ i kəɾ ɪmædʒən ɪɾ ɔl tu wɛl, sʌmwʌn stɛpɪŋ ɪndə ðə hɔl tə si faɪv slɪŋkɪŋ mɛn wɪð wɛpənz ɪn ðɛɹ hænz, ʃaʊɾɪŋ ən əlɑɹm. . . .

All around them Rand could hear the sounds of people stirring, slippers scuffing on the floor, soft murmurs of speech. He did not see anyone, but he could imagine it all too well, someone stepping into the hall to see five slinking men with weapons in their hands, shouting an alarm. . . .

"ɪn ðɛɹ," mæt wɪspɝd, pɔɪntɪŋ tə ə bɪɡ pɛɹ ə slaɪɾɪŋ dɔɹz əhɛd, kɑɹv hændhoʊlz ðɛɹ oʊnli ɔɹnəmɛnteɪʃən. "æt list, ðə dæɡɝ ɪz."

"In there," Mat whispered, pointing to a big pair of sliding doors ahead, carved handholds their only ornamentation. "At least, the dagger is."

ɪŋtʃɹ lʊkt ət hʊɹɪn; ðə snɪfɝ slɪd ðə dɔɹz oʊpən, ən ɪŋtʃɹ lɛp θɹu wɪð ɪz sɔɹd ɹɛɾi. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ wʌn ðɛɹ. ɹænd ən ði ʌðɝz hɝiɾ ɪnsaɪd, ən hʊɹɪn kwɪkli kloʊz ðə dɔɹz bɪhaɪn ðɛm.

Ingtar looked at Hurin; the sniffer slid the doors open, and Ingtar leaped through with his sword ready. There was no one there. Rand and the others hurried inside, and Hurin quickly closed the doors behind them.
