peɪntəd skɹinz hɪɾ ɔl ðə wɔlz ən ɛni ʌðɝ dɔɹz, ən veɪl ðə laɪt kʌmɪŋ θɹu wɪndoʊz ðət hæd tə oʊvɝlʊk ðə stʃɹit. ət wʌn ɛn ə ðə bɪɡ ɹum stʊɾ ə tɔl, sɝkjəlɝ kæbənət. ət ði ʌðɝ wɑz ə smɔl teɪbəl, ðə loʊn tʃɛɹ ɑn ðə kɑɹpət tɝn tə feɪs ɪt. ɹænd hɝɾ ɪŋtʃɹ ɡæsp, bʌɾ i oʊnli fɛlt laɪk hivɪŋ ə saɪ ʌv ɹɪlif. ðə kɝlɪŋ ɡoʊldən hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ sæɾ ɑn ə stæn ɑn ðə teɪbəl. bɪloʊ ɪt, ðə ɹubi ɪn ðə hɪlt ə ði ɔɹneɪt dæɡɝ kɑt ðə laɪt.

Painted screens hid all the walls and any other doors, and veiled the light coming through windows that had to overlook the street. At one end of the big room stood a tall, circular cabinet. At the other was a small table, the lone chair on the carpet turned to face it. Rand heard Ingtar gasp, but he only felt like heaving a sigh of relief. The curling golden Horn of Valere sat on a stand on the table. Below it, the ruby in the hilt of the ornate dagger caught the light.

mæt dɑɹɾɪd tə ðə teɪbəl, snætʃɪŋ hɔɹn ən dæɡɝ. "wi hæv ɪt," hi kɹoʊd, ʃeɪkɪŋ ðə dæɡɝ ɪn ɪz fɪst. "wi hæv boʊθ ə ðɛm."

Mat darted to the table, snatching Horn and dagger. "We have it," he crowed, shaking the dagger in his fist. "We have both of them."

"nɑt soʊ laʊd," pɛɹɪn sɛd wɪð ə wɪns. "wi doʊn əv əm aʊɾ ə hɪɹ, jɛt." hɪz hænz wɝ bɪzi ɑn ðə hæft ə hɪz æks; ðeɪ sim tə wɑnə bi hoʊldɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ ɛls.

"Not so loud," Perrin said with a wince. "We don't have them out of here, yet." His hands were busy on the haft of his axe; they seemed to want to be holding something else.

"ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ." ðəɹ wɑz ʃɪɹ ɑ ɪn ɪŋtʃɹz vɔɪs. hi tʌtʃt ðə hɔɹn hɛzɪɾəntli, tʃɹeɪsɪŋ ə fɪŋɡɝ əlɔŋ ðə sɪlvɝ skɹɪpt ɪnleɪɾ ɝaʊn ðə bɛl ən maʊðɪŋ ðə tʃɹænzleɪʃən, ðən pʊld ɪz hæn bæk wɪð ə ʃɪvɝ ʌv ɪksaɪtmənt. "ɪɾ ɪz. baɪ ðə laɪt, ɪɾ ɪz! aɪm seɪvd."

"The Horn of Valere." There was sheer awe in Ingtar's voice. He touched the Horn hesitantly, tracing a finger along the silver script inlaid around the bell and mouthing the translation, then pulled his hand back with a shiver of excitement. "It is. By the Light, it is! I am saved."

hʊɹɪn wɑz muvɪŋ ðə skɹinz ðət hɪd ðə wɪndoʊz. hi ʃʌv ðə læst aʊɾ ə hɪz weɪ ən pɪɹɾ ɪndə ðə stʃɹit bɪloʊ. "ðoʊz soʊlʒɝz ɑɹ ɔl stɪl ðɛɹ, lʊkɪŋ laɪk ðeɪv tʊk ɹut." hi ʃʌɾɝəd. "ðoʊz . . . θɪŋz, tu."

Hurin was moving the screens that hid the windows. He shoved the last out of his way and peered into the street below. "Those soldiers are all still there, looking like they've took root." He shuddered. "Those . . . things, too."

ɹænd wɛn tə dʒɔɪn hɪm. ðə tu bists wɝ ɡɹoʊm; ðəɹ wɑz noʊ dɪnaɪɪŋ ɪt. "haʊ dɪd ðeɪ. . . ." əz i lɪftəɾ ɪz aɪz fɹəm ðə stʃɹit, wɝdz daɪd. hi wɑz lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ə wɔl ɪndə ðə ɡɑɹɾən ə ðə bɪɡ haʊs əkɹɔs ðə stʃɹit. hi kəd si wɛɹ fɝðɝ wɔlz hæd bɪn tɔɹn daʊn, dʒɔɪnɪŋ ʌðɝ ɡɑɹɾənz tə ɪt. wɪmən sæɾ ɑn bɛntʃɪz ðɛɹ, əɹ stʃɹoʊld əlɔŋ ðə wɔks, ɔlweɪz ɪn pɛɹz. wɪmən lɪŋkt, nɛk tə ɹɪst, baɪ sɪlvɝ liʃɪz. wʌn ə ðə wɪmən wɪð ə kɑlɝ ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk lʊkt ʌp. hi wɑz tu fɑɹ tə meɪk aʊɾ əɹ feɪs klɪɹli, bʌt fəɹ ən ɪnstən ɪt sim ðət ðɛɹ aɪz mɛt, ən i nu. ðə blʌd dʒɹeɪn fɹəm ɪz feɪs. "ɛɡwin," hi bɹiðd.

Rand went to join him. The two beasts were grolm; there was no denying it. "How did they. . . ." As he lifted his eyes from the street, words died. He was looking over a wall into the garden of the big house across the street. He could see where further walls had been torn down, joining other gardens to it. Women sat on benches there, or strolled along the walks, always in pairs. Women linked, neck to wrist, by silver leashes. One of the women with a collar around her neck looked up. He was too far to make out her face clearly, but for an instant it seemed that their eyes met, and he knew. The blood drained from his face. "Egwene," he breathed.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt?" mæt sɛd. "ɛɡwin ɪz seɪf ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn. aɪ wɪʃ aɪ wɝ."

"What are you talking about?" Mat said. "Egwene is safe in Tar Valon. I wish I were."

"ʃiz hɪɹ," ɹænd sɛd. ðə tu wɪmən wɝ tɝnɪŋ, wɔkɪŋ təwɔɹd wʌn ə ðə bɪldɪŋz ɑn ðə fɑɹ saɪɾ ə ðə dʒɔɪnd ɡɑɹɾənz. "ʃi ɪz ðɛɹ, ɹaɪɾ əkɹɔs ðə stʃɹit. oʊ, laɪt, ʃiz wɛɹɪŋ wʌn ə ðoʊz kɑlɝz!"

"She's here," Rand said. The two women were turning, walking toward one of the buildings on the far side of the joined gardens. "She is there, right across the street. Oh, Light, she's wearing one of those collars!"

"ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ?" pɛɹɪn sɛd. hi keɪm tə pɪɹ fɹəm ðə wɪndoʊ. "aɪ doʊn si hɝ, ɹænd. ən - ən aɪ kəd ɹɛkəɡnaɪz əɹ ɪf aɪ dɪd, ivən ət ðɪs dɪstəns."

"Are you sure?" Perrin said. He came to peer from the window. "I don't see her, Rand. And - and I could recognize her if I did, even at this distance."

"aɪ æm ʃʊɹ," ɹænd sɛd. ðə tu wɪmən dɪsəpɪɹɾ ɪndə wʌn ə ðə haʊsəz ðət feɪs ðə nɛkst stʃɹiɾ oʊvɝ. hɪz stʌmək wɑz twɪstəɾ ɪndə ə nɑt. ʃiz səpoʊz tə bi seɪf. ʃiz səpoʊz tə bi ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ. "aɪ hæv tə ɡɛɾ əɹ aʊt. ðə ɹɛst ə jə - "

"I am sure," Rand said. The two women disappeared into one of the houses that faced the next street over. His stomach was twisted into a knot. She is supposed to be safe. She's supposed to be in the White Tower. "I have to get her out. The rest of you - "

"soʊ!" ðə slɝɪŋ vɔɪs wɑz əz sɑft əz ðə saʊn ə ðə dɔɹz slaɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðɛɹ tʃɹæks. "ju ɑɹ nɑɾ u aɪ ɪkspɛktəd."

"So!" The slurring voice was as soft as the sound of the doors sliding in their tracks. "You are not who I expected."

fəɹ ə bɹif moʊmənt, ɹænd stɛɹd. ðə tɔl mæn wɪð ðə ʃeɪvən hɛɾ u hæd stɛpt ɪndə ðə ɹum wɔɹ ə lɔŋ, tʃɹeɪlɪŋ blu ɹoʊb, ən ɪz fɪŋɡɝneɪlz wɝ soʊ lɔŋ ðət ɹænd wʌndɝɾ ɪf i kəd hændəl ɛniθɪŋ. ðə tu mɛn stændɪŋ əbsɪkwiəsli bɪhaɪn ɪm hæɾ oʊnli hæf ðɛɹ dɑɹk hɛɹ ʃeɪvd, ðə ɹɛs hæŋɪŋ ɪn ə dɑɹk bɹeɪd daʊn itʃ mænz ɹaɪt tʃik. wʌn ə ðɛm kɹæɾəld ə ʃið sɔɹɾ ɪn ɪz ɑɹmz.

For a brief moment, Rand stared. The tall man with the shaven head who had stepped into the room wore a long, trailing blue robe, and his fingernails were so long that Rand wondered if he could handle anything. The two men standing obsequiously behind him had only half their dark hair shaved, the rest hanging in a dark braid down each man's right cheek. One of them cradled a sheathed sword in his arms.

ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə moʊmən i hæd fəɹ stɛɹɪŋ, ðən skɹinz tɑpəl tə ɹɪvil, əɾ iðɝ ɛn ə ðə ɹum, ə dɔɹweɪ kɹaʊɾəd wɪð fɔɹ əɹ faɪv sintʃæn soʊlʒɝz, bæɹhɛɾɪd bʌɾ ɑɹmɝd, ən sɔɹdz ɪn hænd.

It was only a moment he had for staring, then screens toppled to reveal, at either end of the room, a doorway crowded with four or five Seanchan soldiers, bareheaded but armored, and swords in hand.

"ju ɑɹ ɪn ðə pɹɛzəns ə ðə haɪ lɔɹd tʃɹɑk," ðə mæn u kæɹid ðə sɔɹd bɪɡæn, stɛɹɪŋ ət ɹænd ən ði ʌðɝz æŋɡɹəli, bʌɾ ə bɹif moʊʃən ʌv ə fɪŋɡɝ wɪð ə blu-lækɝd neɪl kʌɾ ɪm ʃɔɹt. ði ʌðɝ sɝvən stɛp fɔɹwɝd wɪð ə baʊ ən bɪɡæn ənduɪŋ tʃɹɑks ɹoʊb.

"You are in the presence of the High Lord Turak," the man who carried the sword began, staring at Rand and the others angrily, but a brief motion of a finger with a blue-lacquered nail cut him short. The other servant stepped forward with a bow and began undoing Turak's robe.

"wɛn wʌn ə maɪ ɡɑɹdz wɑz faʊn dɛd," ðə ʃeɪvən-hɛɾəd mæn sɛd kɑmli, "aɪ səspɛktəd ðə mæn u kɔlz hɪmsɛlf feɪn. aɪ hæv bɪn səspɪʃəs ə hɪm sɪns hwɑn daɪd soʊ mɪstɪɹiəsli, ən hiz ɔlweɪz wɑntəd ðət dæɡɝ." hi hɛld aʊɾ ɪz ɑɹmz fəɹ ðə sɝvən tə ɹimuv ɪz ɹoʊb. dɪspaɪɾ ɪz sɑft, ɔlmoʊst-sɪŋɪŋ vɔɪs, hɑɹd mʌsəlz ɹoʊpt ɪz ɑɹmz ən smuð tʃɛst, wɪtʃ wɑz bɛɹ tə ə blu sæʃ hoʊldɪŋ waɪd, waɪt tʃɹaʊzɝz ðət simd meɪɾ ə hʌnʒɹədz ə plits. hi saʊndəɾ ənɪntʃɹəstəd, ən ɪndɪfɹən tə ðə bleɪdz ɪn ðɛɹ hænz. "ænd naʊ tə faɪn stʃɹeɪnʒɝz wɪð nɑɾ oʊnli ðə dæɡɝ, bʌt ðə hɔɹn. ɪɾəl pliz mi tə kɪl wʌn əɹ tu ʌv jə fəɹ dɪstɝbɪŋ maɪ mɔɹnɪŋ. ðoʊz u sɝvaɪv wɪl tɛl mi ʌv u jə ɑɹ ən waɪ jə keɪm." hi stʃɹɛtʃt aʊɾ ə hænd wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ - ðə mæn wɪð ðə skæbɑɹɾɪd sɔɹd leɪd ðə hɪlt ɪn ðə hænd - ən dʒɹu ðə hɛvi, kɝv bleɪd. "aɪ wəd nɑɾ əv ðə hɔɹn dæmədʒd."

"When one of my guards was found dead," the shaven-headed man said calmly, "I suspected the man who calls himself Fain. I have been suspicious of him since Huan died so mysteriously, and he has always wanted that dagger." He held out his arms for the servant to remove his robe. Despite his soft, almost-singing voice, hard muscles roped his arms and smooth chest, which was bare to a blue sash holding wide, white trousers that seemed made of hundreds of pleats. He sounded uninterested, and indifferent to the blades in their hands. "And now to find strangers with not only the dagger, but the Horn. It will please me to kill one or two of you for disturbing my morning. Those who survive will tell me of who you are and why you came." He stretched out a hand without looking - the man with the scabbarded sword laid the hilt in the hand - and drew the heavy, curved blade. "I would not have the Horn damaged."

tʃɹɑk ɡeɪv noʊ ʌðɝ sɪɡnəl, bʌt wʌn ə ðə soʊlʒɝz stɔkt ɪndə ðə ɹum ən ɹitʃt fəɹ ðə hɔɹn. ɹænd dɪd nɑt noʊ wɛðɝ i ʃəd læf, əɹ nɑt. ðə mæn wɔɹ ɑɹmɝ, bʌɾ ɪz ɛɹəɡən feɪs simd əz əblɪviəs tə ðɛɹ wɛpənz əz tʃɹɑk wɑz.

Turak gave no other signal, but one of the soldiers stalked into the room and reached for the Horn. Rand did not know whether he should laugh, or not. The man wore armor, but his arrogant face seemed as oblivious to their weapons as Turak was.

mæt pʊɾ ən ɛn tə ɪt. əz ðə sintʃæn ɹitʃt aʊɾ ɪz hænd, mæt slæʃt ɪt wɪð ðə ɹubi-hɪltɪd dæɡɝ. wɪð ə kɝs, ðə soʊlʒɝ lɛp bæk, lʊkɪŋ sɝpɹaɪzd. ən ðən i skɹimd. ɪt tʃɪl ðə ɹum, hɛld ɛvɹiwʌn wɛɹ ðeɪ stʊɾ ɪn əstɑnɪʃmənt. ðə tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ hæn i hɛld ʌp ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪz feɪs wɑz tɝnɪŋ blæk, dɑɹknəs kɹipɪŋ aʊtwɝdz fɹəm ðə bliɾɪŋ ɡæʃ ðət kɹɔst ɪz pɑm. hi oʊpən ɪz maʊθ waɪɾ ən haʊld, klɔɪŋ əɾ ɪz ɑɹm, ðən ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. kɪkɪŋ, dʒɝkɪŋ, hi tɑpəl tə ðə flɔɹ, θɹæʃɪŋ ɑn ðə sɪlkən kɑɹpət, ʃɹikɪŋ əz ɪz feɪs ɡɹu blæk ən ɪz dɑɹk aɪz bʌlʒd laɪk oʊvɝɹaɪp plʌmz, əntɪl ə dɑɹk, swoʊlən tʌŋ ɡæɡd hɪm. hi twɪtʃt, tʃoʊkɪŋ ɹæədli, hilz dʒɹʌmɪŋ, ən dɪd nɑt muv əɡɛn. ɛvɹi bɪɾ ə hɪz ɪkspoʊz flɛʃ wɑz blæk əz pjutʃɹɪd pɪtʃ ən lʊkt ɹɛɾi tə bɝst əɾ ə tʌtʃ.

Mat put an end to it. As the Seanchan reached out his hand, Mat slashed it with the ruby-hilted dagger. With a curse, the soldier leaped back, looking surprised. And then he screamed. It chilled the room, held everyone where they stood in astonishment. The trembling hand he held up in front of his face was turning black, darkness creeping outwards from the bleeding gash that crossed his palm. He opened his mouth wide and howled, clawing at his arm, then his shoulder. Kicking, jerking, he toppled to the floor, thrashing on the silken carpet, shrieking as his face grew black and his dark eyes bulged like overripe plums, until a dark, swollen tongue gagged him. He twitched, choking raggedly, heels drumming, and did not move again. Every bit of his exposed flesh was black as putrid pitch and looked ready to burst at a touch.

mæt lɪkt ɪz lɪps ən swɑloʊd; hɪz ɡɹɪp ʃɪftəɾ ənizəli ɑn ðə dæɡɝ. ivən tʃɹɑk stɛɹd, oʊpənməðd.

Mat licked his lips and swallowed; his grip shifted uneasily on the dagger. Even Turak stared, openmouthed.

"ju si," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd sɔfli, "wi ɑɹ noʊ izi mit." sʌɾənli hi lɛpt oʊvɝ ðə kɔɹps, təwɔɹd ðə soʊlʒɝz stɪl ɡɑəlɪŋ ət wʌt wɑz lɛft ə ðə mæn u hæd stʊɾ ət ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz oʊnli moʊməns bɪfɔɹ. "ʃɪnoʊwə!" hi kɹaɪd. "fɑloʊ mi!" hʊɹɪn lɛpt æftɝ hɪm, ən ðə soʊlʒɝz fɛl bæk bɪfɔɹ ðɛm, ðə saʊnz ə stil ɑn stil ɹaɪzɪŋ.

"You see," Ingtar said softly, "we are no easy meat." Suddenly he leaped over the corpse, toward the soldiers still goggling at what was left of the man who had stood at their shoulders only moments before. "Shinowa!" he cried. "Follow me!" Hurin leaped after him, and the soldiers fell back before them, the sounds of steel on steel rising.

ðə sintʃæn ət ði ʌðɝ ɛn ə ðə ɹum stɑɹɾəd fɔɹwɝɾ əz ɪŋtʃɹ muvd, bʌt ðən ðeɪ wɝ fɔlɪŋ bæk, tu, bɪfɔɹ mæts θɹʌstɪŋ dæɡɝ ivən mɔɹ ðən fɹəm ði æks pɛɹɪn swʌŋ wɪð wɝdləs snɑɹlz.

The Seanchan at the other end of the room started forward as Ingtar moved, but then they were falling back, too, before Mat's thrusting dagger even more than from the axe Perrin swung with wordless snarls.

ɪn ðə speɪs ə hɑɹtbits, ɹænd stʊɾ əloʊn, feɪsɪŋ tʃɹɑk, hu hɛld ɪz bleɪɾ əpɹaɪt bɪfɔɹ hɪm. hɪz moʊmən ə ʃɑk wɑz ɡɔn. hɪz aɪz wɝ ʃɑɹp ɑn ɹændz feɪs; ðə blæk ən swoʊlən bɑɾi ʌv wʌn ə hɪz soʊlʒɝz maɪɾ əz wɛl nɑɾ əv ɪɡzɪstəd. ɪt dɪd nɑt sim tə ɪɡzɪs fəɹ ðə tu sɝvəns, iðɝ, ɛni mɔɹ ðən ɹænd ən ɪz sɔɹɾ ɪɡzɪstəd, əɹ ðə saʊnz ə faɪɾɪŋ, feɪɾɪŋ naʊ fɹəm ðə ɹumz tə iðɝ saɪɾ aʊɾ ɪndə ðə haʊs. ðə sɝvəns hæd bɪɡʌn kɑmli foʊldɪŋ tʃɹɑks ɹoʊb əz sun əz ðə haɪ lɔɹd tʊk ɪz sɔɹd, ən hæd nɑt lʊkt ʌp ivən fəɹ ðə dɛd soʊlʒɝz ʃɹiks; naʊ ðeɪ nɛl bɪsaɪd ðə dɔɹ ən wɑtʃt wɪð ɪmpæsɪv aɪz.

In the space of heartbeats, Rand stood alone, facing Turak, who held his blade upright before him. His moment of shock was gone. His eyes were sharp on Rand's face; the black and swollen body of one of his soldiers might as well not have existed. It did not seem to exist for the two servants, either, any more than Rand and his sword existed, or the sounds of fighting, fading now from the rooms to either side out into the house. The servants had begun calmly folding Turak's robe as soon as the High Lord took his sword, and had not looked up even for the dead soldier's shrieks; now they knelt beside the door and watched with impassive eyes.

"aɪ səspɛktəɾ ɪt maɪt kʌm tə jə ən mi." tʃɹɑk spʌn ɪz bleɪɾ izəli, ə fʊl sɝkəl wʌn weɪ, ðən ði ʌðɝ, hɪz lɔŋ-neɪl fɪŋɡɝz muvɪŋ dɛləkətli ɑn ðə hɪlt. hɪz fɪŋɡɝneɪlz dɪd nɑt sim tə hæmpɝ ɪm əɾ ɔl. "ju ɑɹ jʌŋ. lɛɾ əs si wʌɾ ɪz ɹikwaɪɝd tə ɝn ðə hɛɹən ɑn ðɪs saɪɾ ə ði oʊʃən."

"I suspected it might come to you and me." Turak spun his blade easily, a full circle one way, then the other, his long-nailed fingers moving delicately on the hilt. His fingernails did not seem to hamper him at all. "You are young. Let us see what is required to earn the heron on this side of the ocean."

sʌɾənli ɹænd sɔ. stændɪŋ tɔl ɑn tʃɹɑks bleɪd wɑz ə hɛɹən. wɪð ðə lɪɾəl tʃɹeɪnɪŋ i hæd, hi wɑz feɪs-tə-feɪs wɪð ə ɹil bleɪdmæstɝ. heɪstəli hi tɔs ðə flis-laɪn kloʊk əsaɪd, ɹɪɾɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ʌv weɪɾ ən ɛnkʌmbɹəns. tʃɹɑk weɪɾəd.

Suddenly Rand saw. Standing tall on Turak's blade was a heron. With the little training he had, he was face-to-face with a real blademaster. Hastily he tossed the fleece-lined cloak aside, ridding himself of weight and encumbrance. Turak waited.

ɹænd dɛspɝətli wɑntəd tə sik ðə vɔɪd. ɪt wɑz pleɪn i wəd niɾ ɛvɹi ʃɹɛɾ ʌv əbɪləɾi hi kəd mʌstɝ, ən ivən ðən ɪz tʃænsəz ə livɪŋ ðə ɹum əlaɪv wəd bi smɔl. hi hæd tə liv əlaɪv. ɛɡwin wɑz ɔlmoʊs kloʊs ɪnʌf fəɹ ɪm tə ʃaʊt tə hɝ, ən i hæd tə fɹi hɝ, sʌmhaʊ. bʌt seɪɾɪn weɪɾəd ɪn ðə vɔɪd. ðə θɔt meɪɾ ɪz hɑɹt lip wɪð iɡɝnəs ət ðə seɪm taɪm ðəɾ ɪt tɝn ɪz stʌmək. bʌt dʒʌst əz kloʊs əz ɛɡwin wɝ ðoʊz ʌðɝ wɪmən. deɪmeɪn. ɪf i tʌtʃt seɪɾɪn, ən ɪf i kəd nɑt stɑp hɪmsɛlf tʃænəlɪŋ, ðeɪ wəd noʊ, vɛɹɪn hæd toʊl hɪm. noʊ ən wʌndɝ. soʊ mɛni, soʊ kloʊs. hi maɪt sɝvaɪv tʃɹɑk oʊnli tə daɪ feɪsɪŋ deɪmeɪn, ən i kəd nɑt daɪ bɪfɔɹ ɛɡwin wɑz fɹi. ɹænd ɹeɪzd ɪz bleɪd.

Rand desperately wanted to seek the void. It was plain he would need every shred of ability he could muster, and even then his chances of leaving the room alive would be small. He had to leave alive. Egwene was almost close enough for him to shout to her, and he had to free her, somehow. But saidin waited in the void. The thought made his heart leap with eagerness at the same time that it turned his stomach. But just as close as Egwene were those other women. Damane. If he touched saidin, and if he could not stop himself channeling, they would know, Verin had told him. Know and wonder. So many, so close. He might survive Turak only to die facing damane, and he could not die before Egwene was free. Rand raised his blade.

tʃɹɑk ɡlaɪɾɪd təwɔɹɾ ɪm ɑn saɪlən fit. bleɪd ɹæŋ ɑn bleɪd laɪk hæmɝ ɑn ænvəl.

Turak glided toward him on silent feet. Blade rang on blade like hammer on anvil.

fɹəm ðə fɝst ɪt wɑz klɪɹ tə ɹænd ðət ðə mæn wɑz tɛstɪŋ hɪm, pʊʃɪŋ oʊnli hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf tə si wʌɾ i kəd du, ðən pʊʃɪŋ ə lɪɾəl hɑɹɾɝ, ðən dʒʌst ə lɪɾəl hɑɹɾɝ stɪl. ɪt wɑz kwɪk ɹɪsts ən kwɪk fit ðət kɛpt ɹænd əlaɪv əz mʌtʃ əz skɪl. wɪθaʊt ðə vɔɪd, hi wɑz ɔlweɪz hæf ə hɑɹtbit bɪhaɪnd. ðə tɪp ə tʃɹɑks hɛvi sɔɹd meɪɾ ə stɪŋɪŋ tʃɹɛntʃ dʒʌst ʌndɝ ɪz lɛft aɪ. ə flæp ə koʊt sliv hʌŋ əweɪ fɹəm ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, ðə dɑɹkɝ fəɹ biɪŋ wɛt. ʌndɝ ə nit slæʃ bɪniθ ɪz ɹaɪɾ ɑɹm, pɹɪsaɪs əz ə teɪlɝz kʌt, hi kəd fil wɔɹm dæmpnəs spɹɛɾɪŋ daʊn ɪz ɹɪbz.

From the first it was clear to Rand that the man was testing him, pushing only hard enough to see what he could do, then pushing a little harder, then just a little harder still. It was quick wrists and quick feet that kept Rand alive as much as skill. Without the void, he was always half a heartbeat behind. The tip of Turak's heavy sword made a stinging trench just under his left eye. A flap of coat sleeve hung away from his shoulder, the darker for being wet. Under a neat slash beneath his right arm, precise as a tailor's cut, he could feel warm dampness spreading down his ribs.

ðəɹ wɑz dɪsəpɔɪnmənt ɑn ðə haɪ lɔɹdz feɪs. hi stɛp bæk wɪð ə dʒɛstʃɝ ə dɪsɡʌst. "wɛɹ dɪd jə faɪn ðət bleɪd, bɔɪ? əɹ də ðeɪ hɪɹ tʃɹuli əwɔɹd ðə hɛɹən tə ðoʊz noʊ mɔɹ skɪl ðən ju? noʊ mæɾɝ. meɪk jəɹ pis. ɪts taɪm tə daɪ." hi keɪm ɑn əɡɛn.

There was disappointment on the High Lord's face. He stepped back with a gesture of disgust. "Where did you find that blade, boy? Or do they here truly award the heron to those no more skilled than you? No matter. Make your peace. It is time to die." He came on again.

ðə vɔɪɾ ɛnvɛləpt ɹænd. seɪɾɪn floʊd təwɔɹd hɪm, ɡloʊɪŋ wɪð ðə pɹɑməs ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ, bʌɾ i ɪɡnɔɹɾ ɪt. ɪt wɑz noʊ mɔɹ dɪfəkəl ðən ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ə bɑɹb θɔɹn twɪstɪŋ ɪn ɪz flɛʃ. hi ɹəfjuz tə bi fɪld wɪð ðə paʊɝ, ɹəfjuz tə bi wʌn wɪð ðə meɪl hæf ə ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs. hi wɑz wʌn wɪð ðə sɔɹɾ ɪn ɪz hænz, wʌn wɪð ðə flɔɹ bɪniθ ɪz fit, wʌn wɪð ðə wɔlz. wʌn wɪð tʃɹɑk.

The void enveloped Rand. Saidin flowed toward him, glowing with the promise of the One Power, but he ignored it. It was no more difficult than ignoring a barbed thorn twisting in his flesh. He refused to be filled with the Power, refused to be one with the male half of the True Source. He was one with the sword in his hands, one with the floor beneath his feet, one with the walls. One with Turak.

hi ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə fɔɹmz ðə haɪ lɔɹd juzd; ðeɪ wɝ ə lɪɾəl dɪfɹən fɹəm wʌɾ i hæd bɪn tɔt, bʌt nɑɾ ɪnʌf. ðə swɑloʊ teɪks flaɪt mɛt pɑɹɾɪŋ ðə sɪlk. mun ɑn ðə wɔɾɝ mɛt ðə wʊd ɡɹaʊs dænsəz. ɹɪbən ɪn ði ɛɹ mɛt stoʊnz fɔlɪŋ fɹəm ðə klɪf. ðeɪ muvd əbaʊt ðə ɹum əz ɪn ə dæns, ən ðɛɹ mjuzɪk wɑz stil əɡɛnst stil.

He recognized the forms the High Lord used; they were a little different from what he had been taught, but not enough. The Swallow Takes Flight met Parting the Silk. Moon on the Water met The Wood Grouse Dances. Ribbon in the Air met Stones Falling From the Cliff. They moved about the room as in a dance, and their music was steel against steel.

dɪsəpɔɪnmənt ən dɪsɡʌs feɪɾəd fɹəm tʃɹɑks dɑɹk aɪz, ɹipleɪs baɪ sɝpɹaɪz, ðən kɑnsəntʃɹeɪʃən. swɛɾ əpɪɹɾ ɑn ðə haɪ lɔɹdz feɪs əz i pɹɛst ɹænd hɑɹɾɝ. laɪtnɪŋ ə θɹi pɹɔŋz mɛt lif ɑn ðə bɹiz.

Disappointment and disgust faded from Turak's dark eyes, replaced by surprise, then concentration. Sweat appeared on the High Lord's face as he pressed Rand harder. Lightning of Three Prongs met Leaf on the Breeze.

ɹændz θɔts floʊɾəd aʊtsaɪd ðə vɔɪd, əpɑɹt fɹəm hɪmsɛlf, hɑɹdli noʊɾəst. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ɪnʌf. hi feɪst ə bleɪd-mæstɝ, ən wɪð ðə vɔɪɾ ən ɛvɹi aʊns ə hɪz skɪl i wɑz bɛɹli mænɪdʒɪŋ tə hoʊld ɪz oʊn. bɛɹli. hi hæd tə ɛn ɪt bɪfɔɹ tʃɹɑk faɪnəli dɪd. seɪɾɪn? noʊ! səmtaɪmz ɪts nɛsəsɛɹi tə ʃið ðə sɔɹɾ ɪn jəɹ oʊn flɛʃ. bʌt ðət wəd nɑt hɛlp ɛɡwin, iðɝ. hi hæd tə ɛn ɪt naʊ. naʊ.

Rand's thoughts floated outside the void, apart from himself, hardly noticed. It was not enough. He faced a blade-master, and with the void and every ounce of his skill he was barely managing to hold his own. Barely. He had to end it before Turak finally did. Saidin? No! Sometimes it is necessary to Sheathe the Sword in your own flesh. But that would not help Egwene, either. He had to end it now. Now.

tʃɹɑks aɪz waɪɾənd əz ɹænd ɡlaɪɾɪd fɔɹwɝd. soʊ fɑɹ i hæɾ oʊnli dɪfɛndəd; naʊ hi ətækt, ɔl aʊt. ðə bɔɹ ɹʌʃəz daʊn ðə maʊntən. ɛvɹi muvmən ə hɪz bleɪd wɑz ən ətɛmp tə ɹitʃ ðə haɪ lɔɹd; naʊ ɔl tʃɹɑk kəd də wɑz ɹitʃɹiɾ ən dɪfɛnd, daʊn ðə lɛŋθ ə ðə ɹum, ɔlmoʊs tə ðə dɔɹ.

Turak's eyes widened as Rand glided forward. So far he had only defended; now he attacked, all out. The Boar Rushes Down the Mountain. Every movement of his blade was an attempt to reach the High Lord; now all Turak could do was retreat and defend, down the length of the room, almost to the door.

ɪn ən ɪnstənt, waɪl tʃɹɑk stɪl tʃɹaɪd tə feɪs ðə bɔɹ, ɹænd tʃɑɹdʒd. ðə ɹɪvɝ ʌndɝkʌts ðə bæŋk. hi dʒɹɑp tə wʌn ni, bleɪd slæʃɪŋ əkɹɔs. hi dɪd nɑt nid tʃɹɑks ɡæsp, əɹ ðə fil ə ɹɪzɪstəns tə hɪz kʌt tə noʊ. hi hɝd tu θʌmps ən tɝn ɪz hɛd, noʊɪŋ wʌɾ i wəd si. hi lʊk daʊn ðə lɛŋθ ə hɪz bleɪd, wɛɾ ən ɹɛd, tə wɛɹ ðə haɪ lɔɹd leɪ, sɔɹd tʌmbəl fɹəm ɪz lɪmp hænd, ə dɑɹk dæmpnəs steɪnɪŋ ðə bɝdz woʊvən ɪn ðə kɑɹpəɾ ʌndɝ ɪz bɑɾi. tʃɹɑks aɪz wɝ stɪl oʊpən, bʌɾ ɔlɹɛɾi fɪlmd wɪð dɛθ.

In an instant, while Turak still tried to face the Boar, Rand charged. The River Undercuts the Bank. He dropped to one knee, blade slashing across. He did not need Turak's gasp, or the feel of resistance to his cut to know. He heard two thumps and turned his head, knowing what he would see. He looked down the length of his blade, wet and red, to where the High Lord lay, sword tumbled from his limp hand, a dark dampness staining the birds woven in the carpet under his body. Turak's eyes were still open, but already filmed with death.

ðə vɔɪd ʃʊk. hi hæd feɪs tʃɹɑləks bɪfɔɹ, feɪst ʃæɾoʊzpɔn. nɛvɝ bɪfɔɹ hæɾ i kənfɹʌntəɾ ə hjumən biɪŋ wɪð ə sɔɹɾ ɪksɛpt ɪn pɹæktəs əɹ blʌf. aɪ dʒʌs kɪld ə mæn. ðə vɔɪd ʃʊk, ən seɪɾɪn tʃɹaɪd tə fɪl hɪm.

The void shook. He had faced Trollocs before, faced Shadowspawn. Never before had he confronted a human being with a sword except in practice or bluff. I just killed a man. The void shook, and saidin tried to fill him.

dɛspɝətli hi klɔd fɹi, bɹiðɪŋ hɑɹɾ əz i lʊkt ɝaʊnd. hi ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt wən i sɔ ðə tu sɝvəns stɪl nilɪŋ bɪsaɪd ðə dɔɹ. hi hæd fɝɡɑɾən ðɛm, ən naʊ hi dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt tə də əbaʊt ðɛm. niðɝ mæn əpɪɹɾ ɑɹmd, jɛɾ ɔl ðeɪ hæd tə də wɑz ʃaʊt. . . .

Desperately he clawed free, breathing hard as he looked around. He gave a start when he saw the two servants still kneeling beside the door. He had forgotten them, and now he did not know what to do about them. Neither man appeared armed, yet all they had to do was shout. . . .

ðeɪ nɛvɝ lʊkt ət hɪm, əɹ əɾ itʃ ʌðɝ. ɪnstɛd, ðeɪ stɛɹd saɪlənli ət ðə haɪ lɔɹdz bɑɾi. ðeɪ pɹədus dæɡɝz fɹəm ʌndɝ ðɛɹ ɹoʊbz, ən i taɪɾənd ɪz ɡɹɪp ɑn ðə sɔɹd, bʌɾ itʃ mæn pleɪs ðə pɔɪn tə hɪz oʊn bɹɛst. "fɹʌm bɝθ tə dɛθ," ðeɪ ɪntoʊn ɪn junəsən, "aɪ sɝv ðə blʌd." ən plʌnʒd ðə dæɡɝz ɪndə ðɛɹ oʊn hɑɹts. ðeɪ foʊldəd fɔɹwɝɾ ɔlmoʊs pisfəli, hɛdz tə ðə flɔɹ əz ɪf boʊɪŋ dipli tə ðɛɹ lɔɹd.

They never looked at him, or at each other. Instead, they stared silently at the High Lord's body. They produced daggers from under their robes, and he tightened his grip on the sword, but each man placed the point to his own breast. "From birth to death," they intoned in unison, "I serve the Blood." And plunged the daggers into their own hearts. They folded forward almost peacefully, heads to the floor as if bowing deeply to their lord.

ɹænd stɛɹɾ əɾ əm ɪn dɪsbɪlif. mæd, hi θɔt. meɪbi əl ɡoʊ mæd, bʌt ðeɪ ɔlɹɛɾi wɝ.

Rand stared at them in disbelief. Mad, he thought. Maybe I will go mad, but they already were.

hi wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ tə hɪz fit ʃɑkəli wən ɪŋtʃɹ ən ði ʌðɝz keɪm ɹʌnɪŋ bæk. ðeɪ ɔl bɔɹ nɪks ən kʌts; ðə lɛðɝ ʌv ɪŋtʃɹz koʊt wɑz steɪn ɪn mɔɹ ðən wʌn pleɪs. mæt stɪl hæd ðə hɔɹn ən ɪz dæɡɝ, ɪts bleɪd dɑɹkɝ ðən ðə ɹubi ɪn ɪts hɪlt. pɛɹɪnz æks wɑz ɹɛd, tu, ən i lʊkt əz ɪf i maɪt bi sɪk əɾ ɛni moʊmənt.

He was getting to his feet shakily when Ingtar and the others came running back. They all bore nicks and cuts; the leather of Ingtar's coat was stained in more than one place. Mat still had the Horn and his dagger, its blade darker than the ruby in its hilt. Perrin's axe was red, too, and he looked as if he might be sick at any moment.

"ju dɛlt wɪð ðɛm?" ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd, lʊkɪŋ ət ðə bɑɾiz. "ðɛn wɝ dʌn, ɪf noʊ əlɑɹm ɪz ɡɪvən. ðoʊz fulz nɛvɝ kɹaɪd fəɹ hɛlp, nɑt wʌns."

"You dealt with them?" Ingtar said, looking at the bodies. "Then we're done, if no alarm is given. Those fools never cried for help, not once."

"aɪ wɪl si ɪf ðə ɡɑɹdz hɝɾ ɛniθɪŋ," hʊɹɪn sɛd, ən dɑɹɾɪd fəɹ ðə wɪndoʊ.

"I will see if the guards heard anything," Hurin said, and darted for the window.

mæt ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ɹænd, ðiz pipəl ɑɹ kɹeɪzi. aɪ noʊ aɪv sɛd ðət bɪfɔɹ, bʌt ðiz pipəl ɹɪli ɑɹ. ðoʊz sɝvəns. . . ." ɹænd hɛld ɪz bɹɛθ, wʌndɝɪŋ ɪf ðeɪ hæɾ ɔl kɪl ðɛmsɛlvz. mæt sɛd, "wɛnɛvɝ ðeɪ sɔ əs faɪɾɪŋ, ðeɪ fɛl ɑn ðɛɹ niz, pʊt ðɛɹ feɪsəz tə ðə flɔɹ, ən ɹæp ðɛɹ ɑɹmz ɝaʊn ðɛɹ hɛdz. ðeɪ nɛvɝ muvd, əɹ kɹaɪɾ aʊt; nɛvɝ tʃɹaɪd tə hɛlp ðə soʊlʒɝz, əɹ ɡɪv ən əlɑɹm. ðəɹ stɪl ðɛɹ, əz fɑɹ əz aɪ noʊ."

Mat shook his head. "Rand, these people are crazy. I know I've said that before, but these people really are. Those servants. . . ." Rand held his breath, wondering if they had all killed themselves. Mat said, "Whenever they saw us fighting, they fell on their knees, put their faces to the floor, and wrapped their arms around their heads. They never moved, or cried out; never tried to help the soldiers, or give an alarm. They're still there, as far as I know."

"aɪ wəd nɑt kaʊn ɑn əm steɪɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ niz," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd dʒɹaɪli. "wi ɑɹ livɪŋ naʊ, əz fæst əz wi kən ɹʌn."

"I would not count on them staying on their knees," Ingtar said dryly. "We are leaving now, as fast as we can run."

"ju ɡoʊ," ɹænd sɛd. "ɛɡwin - "

"You go," Rand said. "Egwene - "

"ju ful!" ɪŋtʃɹ snæpt. "wi hæv wʌt wi keɪm fɔɹ. ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ. ðə hoʊp ə sælveɪʃən. wʌt kən wʌn ɡɝl kaʊnt, ivən ɪf jə lʌv hɝ, əlɔŋsaɪd ðə hɔɹn, ən wʌɾ ɪt stænz fɔɹ?"

"You fool!" Ingtar snapped. "We have what we came for. The Horn of Valere. The hope of salvation. What can one girl count, even if you love her, alongside the Horn, and what it stands for?"

"ðə dɑɹk wʌn kən əv ðə hɔɹn fəɹ ɔl aɪ kɛɹ! wʌt dʌz faɪndɪŋ ðə hɔɹn kaʊn ɪf ðəfɝst əbændən ɛɡwin tə ðɪs? ɪf aɪ dɪd ðæt, ðə hɔɹn kʊdn seɪv mi. ðə kɹieɪɾɝ kʊdn seɪv mi. aɪ wəd dæm maɪsɛlf."

"The Dark One can have the Horn for all I care! What does finding the Horn count if I abandon Egwene to this? If I did that, the Horn couldn't save me. The Creator couldn't save me. I would damn myself."

ɪŋtʃɹ stɛɹɾ ət hɪm, hɪz feɪs ənɹiɾəbəl. "ju min ðəɾ ɪɡzækli, doʊn ju?"

Ingtar stared at him, his face unreadable. "You mean that exactly, don't you?"

"sʌmθɪŋz hæpənɪŋ aʊt hɪɹ," hʊɹɪn sɛɾ ɝdʒənli. "ə mæn dʒʌs keɪm ɹʌnɪŋ ʌp, ən ðəɹ ɔl mɪlɪŋ laɪk fɪʃ ɪn ə bʌkət. weɪt. ði ɔfəsɝ ɪz kʌmɪŋ ɪnsaɪd!"

"Something's happening out here," Hurin said urgently. "A man just came running up, and they're all milling like fish in a bucket. Wait. The officer is coming inside!"

"ɡoʊ!" ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd. hi tʃɹaɪd tə teɪk ðə hɔɹn, bʌt mæt wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ɹʌnɪŋ. ɹænd hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, bʌɾ ɪŋtʃɹ ɡɹæbd ɪz ɑɹm ən pʊld ɪm ɪndə ðə hɔl. ði ʌðɝz wɝ stʃɹimɪŋ æftɝ mæt; pɛɹɪn oʊnli ɡeɪv ɹænd wʌn peɪn lʊk bɪfɔɹ i wɛnt. "ju kænɑt seɪv ðə ɡɝl ɪf jə stæn hɪɹ ən daɪ!"

"Go!" Ingtar said. He tried to take the Horn, but Mat was already running. Rand hesitated, but Ingtar grabbed his arm and pulled him into the hall. The others were streaming after Mat; Perrin only gave Rand one pained look before he went. "You cannot save the girl if you stand here and die!"

hi ɹæn wɪð ðɛm. pɑɹɾ ə hɪm heɪɾəd hɪmsɛlf fəɹ ɹʌnɪŋ, bʌɾ ənʌðɝ pɑɹt wɪspɝd, əl kʌm bæk. əl fɹi hɝ sʌmhaʊ.

He ran with them. Part of him hated himself for running, but another part whispered, I'll come back. I'll free her somehow.

baɪ ðə taɪm ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə nɛɹoʊ, waɪndɪŋ stɛɹkeɪs, hi kəd hɪɹ ə mænz dip vɔɪs ɹeɪzd ɪn ðə fɹʌn pɑɹɾ ə ðə haʊs, æŋɡɹəli dɪmændɪŋ ðət sʌmwʌn stæn ʌp ən spik. ə sɝvɪŋ ɡɝl ɪn əɹ nɪɹli tʃɹænspɛɹən ɹoʊb nɛlt ət ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə stɛɹz, ən ə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd wʊmən ɔl ɪn waɪt wʊl, wɪð ə lɔŋ flaʊɝi eɪpɹən, nɛl baɪ ðə kɪtʃən dɔɹ. ðeɪ wɝ boʊθ ɪɡzækli əz mæt hæd dɪskɹaɪbd, feɪsəz tə ðə flɔɹ ən ɑɹmz ɹæpt ɝaʊn ðɛɹ hɛdz, ən ðeɪ dɪd nɑt stɝ ə hɛɹ əz ɹænd ən ði ʌðɝz hɝid baɪ. hi wɑz ɹɪliv tə si ðə moʊʃənz ə bɹiðɪŋ.

By the time they reached the bottom of the narrow, winding staircase, he could hear a man's deep voice raised in the front part of the house, angrily demanding that someone stand up and speak. A serving girl in her nearly transparent robe knelt at the bottom of the stairs, and a gray-haired woman all in white wool, with a long floury apron, knelt by the kitchen door. They were both exactly as Mat had described, faces to the floor and arms wrapped around their heads, and they did not stir a hair as Rand and the others hurried by. He was relieved to see the motions of breathing.

ðeɪ kɹɔs ðə ɡɑɹɾən əɾ ə dɛd ɹʌn, klaɪmɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə bæk wɔl ɹæpədli. ɪŋtʃɹ kɝst wən mæt tɔs ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ əhɛɾ ə hɪm, ən tʃɹaɪɾ əɡɛn tə teɪk ɪt wən i dʒɹɑpt aʊtsaɪd, bʌt mæt snætʃt ɪɾ ʌp wɪð ə kwɪk, "ɪɾ ɪzən ivən skɹætʃt," ən skæmpɝɾ ʌp ði æli.

They crossed the garden at a dead run, climbing over the back wall rapidly. Ingtar cursed when Mat tossed the Horn of Valere ahead of him, and tried again to take it when he dropped outside, but Mat snatched it up with a quick, "It isn't even scratched," and scampered up the alley.

mɔɹ ʃaʊts ɹoʊz fɹəm ðə haʊs ðeɪ hæd dʒʌs lɛft; ə wʊmən skɹimd, ən sʌmwʌn bɪɡæn toʊlɪŋ ə ɡɔŋ.

More shouts rose from the house they had just left; a woman screamed, and someone began tolling a gong.

əl kʌm bæk fəɹ hɝ. sʌmhaʊ. ɹænd spɛɾ æftɝ ði ʌðɝz əz fæst əz i kʊd.

I will come back for her. Somehow. Rand sped after the others as fast as he could.


tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾisɪks


CHAPTER 46

tə kʌm aʊɾ ə ðə ʃædoʊ


To Come Out of the Shadow

nɪneɪiv ən ði ʌðɝz hɝd dɪstənt ʃaʊts əz ðeɪ əpɹoʊtʃt ðə bɪldɪŋz wɛɹ ðə deɪmeɪn wɝ haʊzd. ðə kɹaʊdz wɝ bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə pɪk ʌp, ən ðəɹ wɑz ə nɝvəsnəs tə ðə pipəl ɪn ðə stʃɹit, ən ɛkstʃɹə kwɪknəs tə ðɛɹ stɛp, ən ɛkstʃɹə wɛɹinɪs ɪn ðə weɪ ðeɪ ɡlæns pæs nɪneɪiv, ɪn əɹ laɪtnɪŋ-pænəl dʒɹɛs, ən ðə wʊmən ʃi hɛl baɪ ə sɪlvɝ liʃ.

Nynaeve and the others heard distant shouts as they approached the buildings where the damane were housed. The crowds were beginning to pick up, and there was a nervousness to the people in the street, an extra quickness to their step, an extra wariness in the way they glanced past Nynaeve, in her lightning-paneled dress, and the woman she held by a silver leash.

ʃɪftɪŋ əɹ bʌndəl nɝvəsli, ɪleɪn pɪɹd təwɔɹd ðə nɔɪz ə ʃaʊts, wʌn stʃɹiɾ oʊvɝ, wɛɹ ðə ɡoʊldən hɔk klʌtʃɪŋ laɪtnɪŋ ɹɪpəld ɪn ðə wɪnd. "wʌɾ ɪz hæpənɪŋ?"

Shifting her bundle nervously, Elayne peered toward the noise of shouts, one street over, where the golden hawk clutching lightning rippled in the wind. "What is happening?"

"nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ʌs," nɪneɪiv sɛd fɝmli.

"Nothing to do with us," Nynaeve said firmly.

"ju hoʊp," mɪn æɾəd. "æn soʊ də aɪ." ʃi ɪnkɹist əɹ peɪs, hɝiɪŋ ʌp ðə stɛps əhɛɾ ə ði ʌðɝz, ən dɪsəpɪɹɾ ɪnsaɪd ðə tɔl stoʊn haʊs.

"You hope," Min added. "And so do I." She increased her pace, hurrying up the steps ahead of the others, and disappeared inside the tall stone house.

nɪneɪiv ʃɔɹɾənd əɹ ɡɹɪp ɑn ðə liʃ. "ɹɪmɛmbɝ, sɛɾə, jə wɑn əs tə meɪk ɪt θɹu ðɪs seɪfli əz mʌtʃ əz wi du."

Nynaeve shortened her grip on the leash. "Remember, Seta, you want us to make it through this safely as much as we do."

"aɪ du," ðə sintʃæn wʊmən sɛd fɝvənli. ʃi kɛpt əɹ tʃɪn ɑn əɹ tʃɛst, tə haɪɾ əɹ feɪs. "aɪ wɪl kɑz jə noʊ tʃɹʌbəl, aɪ swɛɹ."

"I do," the Seanchan woman said fervently. She kept her chin on her chest, to hide her face. "I will cause you no trouble, I swear."

əz ðeɪ tɝn ʌp ðə ɡɹeɪ stoʊn stɛps, ə sʌldəm ən ə deɪmeɪn əpɪɹɾ ət ðə hɛɾ ə ðə stɛɹz, kʌmɪŋ daʊn əz ðeɪ wɛn ʌp. æftɝ wʌn ɡlæns tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðə wʊmən ɪn ðə kɑlɝ wɑz nɑɾ ɛɡwin, nɪneɪiv dɪd nɑt lʊk əɾ əm əɡɛn. ʃi juz ði æɾəm tə kip sɛɾə kloʊs baɪ hɝ saɪd, soʊ ɪf ðə deɪmeɪn sɛns ði əbɪləɾi tə tʃænəl ɪn wʌn ə ðɛm, ʃi wəd θɪŋk ɪt wɑz sɛɾə. ʃi fɛl swɛt tʃɹɪklɪŋ daʊn əɹ spaɪn, ðoʊ, əntɪl ʃi ɹilaɪz ðeɪ wɝ peɪɪŋ əɹ noʊ mɔɹ ətɛnʃən ðən ʃi ɡeɪv ðɛm. ɔl ðeɪ sɔ wɑz ə dʒɹɛs wɪð laɪtnɪŋ pænəlz ən ə ɡɹeɪ dʒɹɛs, ðə wɪmən wɛɹɪŋ əm lɪŋk baɪ ðə sɪlvɝ lɛŋθ ʌv ən æɾəm. dʒʌst ənʌðɝ liʃ hoʊldɝ wɪð ə liʃt wʌn, ən ə loʊkəl ɡɝl hɝiɪŋ əlɔŋ bɪhaɪnd wɪð ə bʌndəl bɪlɔŋɪŋ tə ðə sʌldəm.

As they turned up the gray stone steps, a sul'dam and a damane appeared at the head of the stairs, coming down as they went up. After one glance to make sure the woman in the collar was not Egwene, Nynaeve did not look at them again. She used the a'dam to keep Seta close by her side, so if the damane sensed the ability to channel in one of them, she would think it was Seta. She felt sweat trickling down her spine, though, until she realized they were paying her no more attention than she gave them. All they saw was a dress with lightning panels and a gray dress, the women wearing them linked by the silver length of an a'dam. Just another Leash Holder with a Leashed One, and a local girl hurrying along behind with a bundle belonging to the sul'dam.

nɪneɪiv pʊʃt oʊpən ðə dɔɹ, ən ðeɪ wɛn ɪn.

Nynaeve pushed open the door, and they went in.

wʌtɛvɝ ði ɪksaɪtmən bɪniθ tʃɹɑks bænɝ, ɪt dɪd nɑɾ ɪkstɛn hɪɹ, nɑt jɛt. ðəɹ wɝ oʊnli wɪmən muvɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪn ði ɛntʃɹi hɔl, ɔl izəli pleɪs baɪ ðɛɹ dʒɹɛs. θɹi ɡɹeɪ-dʒɹɛs deɪmeɪn, wɪð sʌldəm wɛɹɪŋ ðə bɹeɪslɪts. tu wɪmən ɪn dʒɹɛsəz pænəld wɪð fɔɹk laɪtnɪŋ stʊd tɔkɪŋ, ən θɹi kɹɔs ðə hɔl əloʊn. fɔɹ dʒɹɛs laɪk mɪn, ɪn pleɪn dɑɹk wʊlənz, hɝiɾ ɑn ðɛɹ weɪ wɪð tʃɹeɪz.

Whatever the excitement beneath Turak's banner, it did not extend here, not yet. There were only women moving about in the entry hall, all easily placed by their dress. Three gray-dressed damane, with sul'dam wearing the bracelets. Two women in dresses paneled with forked lightning stood talking, and three crossed the hall alone. Four dressed like Min, in plain dark woolens, hurried on their way with trays.

mɪn stʊd weɪɾɪŋ daʊn ði ɛntʃɹi hɔl wən ðeɪ wɛn ɪn; ʃi ɡlænst əɾ əm wʌns, ðən stɑɹɾəd dipɝ ɪndə ðə haʊs. nɪneɪiv ɡaɪɾəd sɛɾə daʊn ðə hɔl æftɝ mɪn, wɪð ɪleɪn skɝiɪŋ əlɔŋ ɪn ðɛɹ weɪk. noʊ wʌn ɡeɪv əm ə sɛkənd ɡlæns, ɪt sim tə nɪneɪiv, bʌt ʃi θɔt ðə tʃɹɪkəl ə swɛt daʊn əɹ bækboʊn maɪt bɪkʌm ə ɹɪvɝ sun. ʃi kɛp sɛɾə muvɪŋ kwɪkli soʊ noʊ wʌn wəɾ əv ə tʃæns fəɹ ə ɡʊd lʊk - əɹ wɝs, ə kwɛstʃən. wɪð əɹ aɪz fɪkst ɑn əɹ toʊz, sɛɾə niɾəd soʊ lɪɾəl ɝdʒɪŋ ðət nɪneɪiv θɔt ʃi wʊɾə bɪn ɹʌnɪŋ ɪf nɑt fəɹ ðə fɪzɪkəl ɹɪstʃɹeɪn ə ðə liʃ.

Min stood waiting down the entry hall when they went in; she glanced at them once, then started deeper into the house. Nynaeve guided Seta down the hall after Min, with Elayne scurrying along in their wake. No one gave them a second glance, it seemed to Nynaeve, but she thought the trickle of sweat down her backbone might become a river soon. She kept Seta moving quickly so no one would have a chance for a good look - or worse, a question. With her eyes fixed on her toes, Seta needed so little urging that Nynaeve thought she would have been running if not for the physical restraint of the leash.

nɪɹ ðə bæk ə ðə haʊs, mɪn tʊk ə nɛɹoʊ stɛɹz ðət spaɪɹəld ʌpwɝdz. nɪneɪiv pʊʃt sɛɾə ʌp ɪɾ əhɛɾ ə hɝ, ɔl ðə weɪ tə ðə fɔɹθ flɔɹ. ðə silɪŋz wɝ loʊ, ðɛɹ, ðə hɔlz ɛmpti ən saɪlən ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə sɑf saʊnz ʌv wipɪŋ. wipɪŋ sim tə fɪt ði ɛɹ ə ðə tʃɪli hɔlz.

Near the back of the house, Min took a narrow stairs that spiraled upwards. Nynaeve pushed Seta up it ahead of her, all the way to the fourth floor. The ceilings were low, there, the halls empty and silent except for the soft sounds of weeping. Weeping seemed to fit the air of the chilly halls.

"ðɪs pleɪs . . ." ɪleɪn bɪɡæn, ðən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "ɪt filz. . . ."

"This place . . ." Elayne began, then shook her head. "It feels. . . ."

"jɛs, ɪt dʌz," nɪneɪiv sɛd ɡɹɪmli. ʃi ɡlɛɹɾ ət sɛɾə, hu kɛpt əɹ feɪs daʊn. ə pælɝ ə fɪɹ meɪd ðə sintʃæn wʊmənz skɪn pəlɝ ðən ɪt wɑz nɔɹməli.

"Yes, it does," Nynaeve said grimly. She glared at Seta, who kept her face down. A pallor of fear made the Seanchan woman's skin paler than it was normally.

wɝdləsli, mɪn oʊpən ə dɔɹ ən wɛn ɪn, ən ðeɪ fɑloʊd. ðə ɹum bɪɑn hæd bɪn dɪvaɪɾəd ɪndə smɔlɝ ɹumz baɪ ɹʌfli meɪd wʊɾən wɔlz, wɪð ə nɛɹoʊ hɔlweɪ ɹʌnɪŋ tə ə wɪndoʊ. nɪneɪiv kɹaʊɾəd æftɝ mɪn əz ʃi hɝid tə ðə læs dɔɹ ɑn ðə ɹaɪɾ ən pʊʃt ɪn.

Wordlessly, Min opened a door and went in, and they followed. The room beyond had been divided into smaller rooms by roughly made wooden walls, with a narrow hallway running to a window. Nynaeve crowded after Min as she hurried to the last door on the right and pushed in.

ə slɛndɝ, dɑɹk-hɛɹd ɡɝl ɪn ɡɹeɪ sæɾ əɾ ə smɔl teɪbəl wɪð əɹ hɛd ɹɛstɪŋ ɑn foʊldəɾ ɑɹmz, bʌɾ ivən bɪfɔɹ ʃi lʊkt ʌp, nɪneɪiv nu ɪt wɑz ɛɡwin. ə ɹɪbən ə ʃaɪnɪŋ mɛɾəl ɹæn fɹəm ðə sɪlvɝ kɑlɝ ɝaʊn ɛɡwinz nɛk tə ə bɹeɪslət hæŋɪŋ ɑn ə pɛɡ ɑn ðə wɔl. hɝ aɪz waɪɾənd ət ðə saɪɾ ə ðɛm, hɝ maʊθ wɝkɪŋ saɪlənli. əz ɪleɪn kloʊz ðə dɔɹ, ɛɡwin ɡeɪv ə sʌɾən ɡɪɡəl, ən pɹɛst əɹ hænz tə hɝ maʊθ tə staɪfəl ɪt. ðə taɪni ɹum wɑz mɔɹ ðən kɹaʊɾəd wɪð ɔl ə ðɛm ɪn ɪt.

A slender, dark-haired girl in gray sat at a small table with her head resting on folded arms, but even before she looked up, Nynaeve knew it was Egwene. A ribbon of shining metal ran from the silver collar around Egwene's neck to a bracelet hanging on a peg on the wall. Her eyes widened at the sight of them, her mouth working silently. As Elayne closed the door, Egwene gave a sudden giggle, and pressed her hands to her mouth to stifle it. The tiny room was more than crowded with all of them in it.

"aɪ noʊ aɪm nɑt dʒɹimɪŋ," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə kwɪvɝɪŋ vɔɪs, "bɪkɔz ɪf aɪ wɑz dʒɹimɪŋ, jud bi ɹænd ən ɡɑləɾ ɑn tɔl stæljənz. aɪ hæv bɪn dʒɹimɪŋ. aɪ θɔt ɹænd wɑz hɪɹ. aɪ kʊdn si hɪm, bʌɾ aɪ θɔt. . . ." hɝ vɔɪs tʃɹeɪld ɔf.

"I know I'm not dreaming," she said in a quivering voice, "because if I was dreaming, you'd be Rand and Galad on tall stallions. I have been dreaming. I thought Rand was here. I couldn't see him, but I thought. . . ." Her voice trailed off.

"ɪf jud ɹæðɝ weɪt fəɹ əm . . ." mɪn sɛd dʒɹaɪli.

"If you'd rather wait for them . . ." Min said dryly.

"oʊ, noʊ. noʊ, jə ɑɹ ɔl bjuɾəfəl, ðə moʊs bjuɾəfəl θɪŋ aɪv ɛvɝ sin. wɛɹ dɪd jə kʌm fɹʌm? haʊ dɪd jə də ɪt? ðət dʒɹɛs, nɪneɪiv, ən ði æɾəm, ən u ɪz. . . ." ʃi ɡeɪv ən əbɹʌp skwik. "ðæts sɛɾə. haʊ . . . ?" hɝ vɔɪs hɑɹɾənd soʊ ðət nɪneɪiv bɛɹli ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd ɪt. "aɪd laɪk tə pʊɾ əɹ ɪn ə pɑɾ ə bɔɪlɪŋ wɔɾɝ." sɛɾə hæɾ əɹ aɪz skwizd ʃʌt, ən əɹ hænz klʌtʃt əɹ skɝts; ʃi wɑz tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ.

"Oh, no. No, you are all beautiful, the most beautiful thing I've ever seen. Where did you come from? How did you do it? That dress, Nynaeve, and the a'dam, and who is. . . ." She gave an abrupt squeak. "That's Seta. How . . . ?" Her voice hardened so that Nynaeve barely recognized it. "I'd like to put her in a pot of boiling water." Seta had her eyes squeezed shut, and her hands clutched her skirts; she was trembling.

"wʌɾ əv ðeɪ dʌn tə ju?" ɪleɪn ɪkskleɪmd. "wʌt kəd ðeɪ də tə meɪk jə wɑn sʌmθɪŋ laɪk ðæt?"

"What have they done to you?" Elayne exclaimed. "What could they do to make you want something like that?"

ɛɡwin nɛvɝ tʊk əɹ aɪz ɔf ðə sintʃæn wʊmən. "aɪd laɪk tə meɪk əɹ fil ɪt. ðæts wʌt ʃi dɪd tə mi, meɪd mi fil laɪk aɪ wɑz nɛk dip ɪn. . . ." ʃi ʃʌɾɝəd. "ju də nɑt noʊ wʌɾ ɪts laɪk wɛɹɪŋ wʌn ə ðiz, ɪleɪn. jə doʊnt noʊ wʌt ðeɪ kən də tə ju. aɪ kən nɛvɝ dɪsaɪd wɛðɝ sɛɾə ɪz wɝs ðən ɹɛnə, bʌt ðəɹ ɔl heɪtfəl."

Egwene never took her eyes off the Seanchan woman. "I'd like to make her feel it. That's what she did to me, made me feel like I was neck deep in. . . ." She shuddered. "You do not know what it is like wearing one of these, Elayne. You don't know what they can do to you. I can never decide whether Seta is worse than Renna, but they're all hateful."

"aɪ θɪŋk aɪ noʊ," nɪneɪiv sɛd kwaɪətli. ʃi kəd fil ðə swɛt soʊkɪŋ sɛɾəz skɪn, ðə koʊl tʃɹɛmɝz ðət ʃʊk əɹ lɪmz. ðə jɛloʊ-hɛɹd sintʃæn wɑz tɛɹəfaɪd. ɪt wɑz ɔl ʃi kəd də nɑt tə meɪk sɛɾəz tɛɹɝz kʌm tʃɹu ðən ən ðɛɹ.

"I think I know," Nynaeve said quietly. She could feel the sweat soaking Seta's skin, the cold tremors that shook her limbs. The yellow-haired Seanchan was terrified. It was all she could do not to make Seta's terrors come true then and there.

"kæn jə teɪk ðɪs ɔf ə mi?" ɛɡwin æskt, tʌtʃɪŋ ðə kɑlɝ. "ju mʌs bi eɪbəl tə ɪf jə kəd pʊt ðət wʌn ɑn - "

"Can you take this off of me?" Egwene asked, touching the collar. "You must be able to if you could put that one on - "

nɪneɪiv tʃænəld, ə pɪnpɔɪn tʃɹɪkəl. ðə kɑlɝ ɑn ɛɡwinz nɛk pɹəvaɪɾəd æŋɡɝ ɪnʌf, ən ɪf ɪt hæd nɑt, sɛɾəz fɪɹ, ðə nɑlədʒ ə haʊ dɪzɝvd ɪt tʃɹuli wɑz, ən əɹ oʊn nɑlədʒ ʌv wʌt ʃi wɑntəd tə də tə ðə wʊmən, wʊɾə dʌn ɪt. ðə kɑlɝ spɹæŋ oʊpən ən fɛl əweɪ fɹəm ɛɡwinz θɹoʊt. wɪð ən ɪkspɹɛʃən ʌv wʌndɝ, ɛɡwin tʌtʃt əɹ nɛk.

Nynaeve channeled, a pinpoint trickle. The collar on Egwene's neck provided anger enough, and if it had not, Seta's fear, the knowledge of how deserved it truly was, and her own knowledge of what she wanted to do to the woman, would have done it. The collar sprang open and fell away from Egwene's throat. With an expression of wonder, Egwene touched her neck.

"pʊɾ ɑn maɪ dʒɹɛs ən koʊt," nɪneɪiv toʊl hɝ. ɪleɪn wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ənbʌnlɪŋ ðə kloʊðz ɑn ðə bɛd. "wi wɪl wɔk aʊɾ ə hɪɹ, ən noʊ wʌn wɪl ivən noʊɾəs ju." ʃi kənsɪɾɝd hoʊldɪŋ əɹ kɑntækt wɪð seɪaɪdɑɹ - ʃi wɑz sɝɾənli æŋɡɹi ɪnʌf, ən ɪt fɛl soʊ wʌndɝfəl - bʌt, ɹɪlʌktənli, ʃi lɛɾ ɪt ɡoʊ. ðɪs wɑz ðə wʌn pleɪs ɪn fɑlm wɛɹ ðəɹ wɑz noʊ tʃæns ʌv ə sʌldəm ən deɪmeɪn kʌmɪŋ tə ɪnvɛstəɡeɪɾ ɪf ðeɪ sɛnst sʌmwʌn tʃænəlɪŋ, bʌt ðeɪ wəd sɝɾənli də soʊ ɪf ə deɪmeɪn sɔ ə wʊmən ʃi θɔt wɑz ə sʌldəm wɪð ðə ɡloʊ ʌv tʃænəlɪŋ ɝaʊn hɝ. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ waɪ jə ɑɹənt ɡɔn ɔlɹɛɾi. əloʊn hɪɹ, ivən ɪf jə kəd nɑt fɪɡjɝ aʊt haʊ tə ɡɛt ðət θɪŋ ɔf ju, jə kəɾ əv dʒʌs pɪkt ɪɾ ʌp ən ɹʌn."

"Put on my dress and coat," Nynaeve told her. Elayne was already unbundling the clothes on the bed. "We will walk out of here, and no one will even notice you." She considered holding her contact with saidar - she was certainly angry enough, and it felt so wonderful - but, reluctantly, she let it go. This was the one place in Falme where there was no chance of a sul'dam and damane coming to investigate if they sensed someone channeling, but they would certainly do so if a damane saw a woman she thought was a sul'dam with the glow of channeling around her. "I don't know why you aren't gone already. Alone here, even if you could not figure out how to get that thing off you, you could have just picked it up and run."

əz mɪn ən ɪleɪn hɝidli hɛlpt əɹ tʃeɪnʒ ɪndə nɪneɪivz oʊl dʒɹɛs, ɛɡwin ɪkspleɪn əbaʊt muvɪŋ ðə bɹeɪslət fɹəm wɛɹ ə sʌldəm lɛft ɪt, ən haʊ tʃænəlɪŋ meɪɾ əɹ sɪk ənlɛs ə sʌldəm wɔɹ ðə bɹeɪslət. dʒʌs ðət mɔɹnɪŋ ʃi hæd dɪskʌvɝd haʊ ðə kɑlɝ kəd bi oʊpənd wɪθaʊt ðə paʊɝ - ən faʊn ðət tʌtʃɪŋ ðə kætʃ wɪð ði ɪntɛntʃən ʌv oʊpənɪŋ ɪt meɪɾ əɹ hænd nɑɾ ɪndə jusləsnəs. ʃi kəd tʌtʃ ɪɾ əz mʌtʃ əz ʃi wɑntəd soʊ lɔŋ əz ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ʌv ənduɪŋ ðə kætʃ; ðə mɛɹəs hɪn ə ðæt, ðoʊ, ænd. . . .

As Min and Elayne hurriedly helped her change into Nynaeve's old dress, Egwene explained about moving the bracelet from where a sul'dam left it, and how channeling made her sick unless a sul'dam wore the bracelet. Just that morning she had discovered how the collar could be opened without the Power - and found that touching the catch with the intention of opening it made her hand knot into uselessness. She could touch it as much as she wanted so long as she did not think of undoing the catch; the merest hint of that, though, and. . . .

nɪneɪiv fɛl sɪk hɝsɛlf. ðə bɹeɪsləɾ ɑn əɹ ɹɪs meɪɾ əɹ sɪk. ɪt wɑz tu hɔɹəbəl. ʃi wɑntəɾ ɪɾ ɔf əɹ ɹɪs bɪfɔɹ ʃi lɝn mɔɹ əbaʊɾ æɾəm, bɪfɔɹ ʃi pɝhæps lɝn sʌmθɪŋ ðət wəd meɪk əɹ fil sɔɪl fɝɛvɝ fəɹ hævɪŋ wɔɹn ɪt.

Nynaeve felt sick herself. The bracelet on her wrist made her sick. It was too horrible. She wanted it off her wrist before she learned more about a'dam, before she perhaps learned something that would make her feel soiled forever for having worn it.

ənfæsənɪŋ ðə sɪlvɝ kʌf, ʃi pʊld ɪt lus, snæpt ɪt kloʊzd, ən hʌŋ ɪɾ ɑn wʌn ə ðə pɛɡz. "doʊn θɪŋk ðət minz jə kən ʃaʊt fəɹ hɛlp naʊ." ʃi ʃʊk ə fɪst ʌndɝ sɛɾəz noʊz. "aɪ kən stɪl meɪk jə wɪʃ jə wɝ nɛvɝ bɔɹn ɪf jə oʊpən jəɹ maʊθ, ən aɪ də nɑt nid ðət blʌɾi . . . θɪŋ."

Unfastening the silver cuff, she pulled it loose, snapped it closed, and hung it on one of the pegs. "Don't think that means you can shout for help now." She shook a fist under Seta's nose. "I can still make you wish you were never born if you open your mouth, and I do not need that bloody . . . thing."

"ju - jə də nɑt min tə liv mi hɪɹ wɪð ɪt," sɛɾə sɛɾ ɪn ə wɪspɝ. "ju kænɑt. taɪ mi. ɡæɡ mi soʊ aɪ kænɑt ɡɪv ən əlɑɹm. pliz!"

"You - you do not mean to leave me here with it," Seta said in a whisper. "You cannot. Tie me. Gag me so I cannot give an alarm. Please!"

ɛɡwin ɡeɪv ə mɝθləs læf. "liv ɪɾ ɑn hɝ. ʃi woʊn kɔl fəɹ hɛlp ivən wɪθaʊɾ ə ɡæɡ. jə hæd bɛɾɝ hoʊp huɛvɝ faɪnz jəl ɹimuv ði æɾəm ən kip jəɹ lɪɾəl sikɹət, sɛɾə. jəɹ dɝɾi sikɹət, ɪzən ɪt?"

Egwene gave a mirthless laugh. "Leave it on her. She won't call for help even without a gag. You had better hope whoever finds you will remove the a'dam and keep your little secret, Seta. Your dirty secret, isn't it?"

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt?" ɪleɪn sɛd.

"What are you talking about?" Elayne said.

"aɪ hæv θɔɾ əbaʊɾ ɪɾ ə ɡɹeɪt dil," ɛɡwin sɛd. "θɪŋkɪŋ wɑz ɔl aɪ kəd də wən ðeɪ lɛf mi əloʊn ʌp hɪɹ. sʌldəm kleɪm ðeɪ dɪvɛləp ən əfɪnəɾi æftɝ ə fju jɪɹz. moʊst ə ðɛm kən tɛl wən ə wʊmən ɪz tʃænəlɪŋ wɛðɝ ðəɹ liʃt tə hɝ əɹ nɑt. aɪ wɑznt ʃʊɹ, bʌt sɛɾə pɹuvz ɪt."

"I have thought about it a great deal," Egwene said. "Thinking was all I could do when they left me alone up here. Sul'dam claim they develop an affinity after a few years. Most of them can tell when a woman is channeling whether they're leashed to her or not. I wasn't sure, but Seta proves it."

"pɹuvz wʌt?" ɪleɪn dɪmændəd, ən ðən əɹ aɪz waɪɾənd ɪn sʌɾən ɹiləzeɪʃən, bʌɾ ɛɡwin wɛn ɑn.

"Proves what?" Elayne demanded, and then her eyes widened in sudden realization, but Egwene went on.

"nɪneɪiv, æɾəm oʊnli wɝk ɑn wɪmən u kən tʃænəl. doʊn jə si? sʌldəm kən tʃænəl ðə seɪm əz deɪmeɪn." sɛɾə ɡɹoʊn θɹu hɝ tiθ, ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛɾ ɪn vaɪələn dɪnaɪəl. "ə sʌldəm wəd daɪ bɪfɔɹ ædmɪɾɪŋ ʃi kəd tʃænəl, ivən ɪf ʃi nu, ən ðeɪ nɛvɝ tʃɹeɪn ði əbɪləɾi, soʊ ðeɪ kænɑt də ɛniθɪŋ wɪð ɪt, bʌt ðeɪ kən tʃænəl."

"Nynaeve, a'dam only work on women who can channel. Don't you see? Sul'dam can channel the same as damane." Seta groaned through her teeth, shaking her head in violent denial. "A sul'dam would die before admitting she could channel, even if she knew, and they never train the ability, so they cannot do anything with it, but they can channel."

"aɪ toʊl ju," mɪn sɛd. "ðæt kɑlɝ ʃʊdn əv wɝkt ɑn hɝ." ʃi wɑz duɪŋ ʌp ðə læs bʌɾənz daʊn ɛɡwinz bæk. "ɛni wʊmən u kʊdn tʃænəl wəd bi eɪbəl tə bit jə sɪli waɪl jə tʃɹaɪd tə kəntʃɹoʊl əɹ wɪð ɪt."

"I told you," Min said. "That collar shouldn't have worked on her." She was doing up the last buttons down Egwene's back. "Any woman who couldn't channel would be able to beat you silly while you tried to control her with it."

"haʊ kən ðət bi?" nɪneɪiv sɛd. "aɪ θɔt ðə sintʃæn pʊt liʃɪz ɑn ɛni wʊmən u kən tʃænəl."

"How can that be?" Nynaeve said. "I thought the Seanchan put leashes on any woman who can channel."

"ɔl ə ðoʊz ðeɪ faɪnd," ɛɡwin toʊl hɝ. "bʌt ðoʊz ðeɪ kən faɪn ɑɹ laɪk ju, ən mi, ən ɪleɪn. wi wɝ bɔɹn wɪð ɪt, ɹɛɾi tə tʃænəl wɛðɝ ɛniwʌn tɔɾ əs əɹ nɑt. bʌt wʌɾ əbaʊt sintʃæn ɡɝlz u ɑɹən bɔɹn wɪð ði əbɪləɾi, bʌɾ u kəd bi tɔt? nɑt dʒʌst ɛni wʊmən kən bɪkʌm ə - ə liʃ hoʊldɝ. ɹɛnə θɔt ʃi wɑz biɪŋ fɹɛnli tɛlɪŋ mi əbaʊɾ ɪt. ɪts əpɛɹənli ə fistdeɪ ɪn sintʃæn vɪlədʒəz wən ðə sʌldəm kʌm tə tɛs ðə ɡɝlz. ðeɪ wɑnə faɪn ɛni laɪk jə ən mi, ən liʃ ðɛm, bʌt ðeɪ lɛɾ ɔl ði ʌðɝz pʊɾ ɑn ə bɹeɪslət tə si ɪf ðeɪ kən fil wʌt ðə pʊɹ wʊmən ɪn ðə kɑlɝ filz. ðoʊz u kən ɑɹ teɪkən əweɪ tə bi tʃɹeɪn əz sʌldəm. ðeɪ ɑɹ ðə wɪmən u kəd bi tɔt."

"All of those they find," Egwene told her. "But those they can find are like you, and me, and Elayne. We were born with it, ready to channel whether anyone taught us or not. But what about Seanchan girls who aren't born with the ability, but who could be taught? Not just any woman can become a - a Leash Holder. Renna thought she was being friendly telling me about it. It is apparently a feastday in Seanchan villages when the sul'dam come to test the girls. They want to find any like you and me, and leash them, but they let all the others put on a bracelet to see if they can feel what the poor woman in the collar feels. Those who can are taken away to be trained as sul'dam. They are the women who could be taught."

sɛɾə wɑz moʊnɪŋ ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ. "noʊ. noʊ. noʊ." oʊvɝ ən oʊvɝ əɡɛn.

Seta was moaning under her breath. "No. No. No." Over and over again.

"aɪ noʊ ʃiz hɔɹəbəl," ɪleɪn sɛd, "bʌɾ aɪ fil əz ɪf aɪ ʃəd hɛlp əɹ sʌmhaʊ. ʃi kəd bi wʌn ʌv əɹ sɪstɝz, oʊnli ðə sintʃæn əv twɪstəɾ ɪɾ ɔl."

"I know she is horrible," Elayne said, "but I feel as if I should help her somehow. She could be one of our sisters, only the Seanchan have twisted it all."

nɪneɪiv oʊpən əɹ maʊθ tə seɪ ðeɪ hæd bɛɾɝ wɝi əbaʊt hɛlpɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz, ən ðə dɔɹ oʊpənd.

Nynaeve opened her mouth to say they had better worry about helping themselves, and the door opened.

"wʌɾ ɪz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn hɪɹ?" ɹɛnə dɪmændəd, stɛpɪŋ ɪndə ðə ɹum. "æn ɑɾiəns?" ʃi stɛɹɾ ət nɪneɪiv, hænz ɑn hɪps. "aɪ nɛvɝ ɡeɪv pɝmɪʃən fəɹ ɛniwʌn ɛls tə lɪŋk wɪð maɪ pɛt, tuli. aɪ də nɑɾ ivən noʊ hu jə - " hɝ aɪz fɛl ɑn ɛɡwin - ɛɡwin wɛɹɪŋ nɪneɪivz dʒɹɛs ɪnstɛɾ ə deɪmeɪn ɡɹeɪ. ɛɡwin wɪð noʊ kɑlɝ ɝaʊn əɹ θɹoʊt - ən əɹ aɪz ɡɹu əz bɪɡ əz sɔsɝz. ʃi nɛvɝ hæɾ ə tʃæns tə jɛl.

"What is going on here?" Renna demanded, stepping into the room. "An audience?" She stared at Nynaeve, hands on hips. "I never gave permission for anyone else to link with my pet, Tuli. I do not even know who you - " Her eyes fell on Egwene - Egwene wearing Nynaeve's dress instead of damane gray. Egwene with no collar around her throat - and her eyes grew as big as saucers. She never had a chance to yell.

bɪfɔɹ ɛniwʌn ɛls kəd muv, ɛɡwin snætʃt ðə pɪtʃɝ fɹəm əɹ wɑʃstæn ən smæʃt ɪɾ ɪndə ɹɛnəz mɪdʒɹəf. ðə pɪtʃɝ ʃæɾɝd, ən ðə sʌldəm lɔst ɔl əɹ bɹɛθ ɪn ə ɡɝɡəlɪŋ ɡæsp ən dʌbəld oʊvɝ. əz ʃi fɛl, ɛɡwin lɛpt ɑn əɹ wɪð ə snɑɹl, ʃʌvɪŋ əɹ flæt, ɡɹæbɪŋ fəɹ ðə kɑlɝ ʃi hæd wɔɹn wɛɹ ɪt stɪl leɪ ɑn ðə flɔɹ, snæpɪŋ ɪɾ ɝaʊn ði ʌðɝ wʊmənz nɛk. wɪð wʌn dʒɝk ɑn ðə sɪlvɝ liʃ, ɛɡwin pʊl ðə bɹeɪslət fɹəm ðə pɛɡ ən fɪɾəd ɪt tə hɝ oʊn ɹɪst. hɝ lɪps wɝ pʊl bæk fɹəm əɹ tiθ, hɝ aɪz fɪkst ɑn ɹɛnəz feɪs wɪð ə tɛɹəbəl kɑnsəntʃɹeɪʃən. nilɪŋ ɑn ðə sʌldəmz ʃoʊldɝz, ʃi pɹɛs boʊθ hænz oʊvɝ ðə wʊmənz maʊθ. ɹɛnə ɡeɪv ə tʃɹəmɛndəs kənvʌlʃən, ən əɹ aɪz bʌlʒd ɪn əɹ feɪs; hɔɹs saʊnz keɪm fɹəm əɹ θɹoʊt, skɹimz hɛl bæk baɪ ɛɡwinz hænz; hɝ hilz dʒɹʌmd ɑn ðə flɔɹ.

Before anyone else could move, Egwene snatched the pitcher from her washstand and smashed it into Renna's midriff. The pitcher shattered, and the sul'dam lost all her breath in a gurgling gasp and doubled over. As she fell, Egwene leaped on her with a snarl, shoving her flat, grabbing for the collar she had worn where it still lay on the floor, snapping it around the other woman's neck. With one jerk on the silver leash, Egwene pulled the bracelet from the peg and fitted it to her own wrist. Her lips were pulled back from her teeth, her eyes fixed on Renna's face with a terrible concentration. Kneeling on the sul'dam's shoulders, she pressed both hands over the woman's mouth. Renna gave a tremendous convulsion, and her eyes bulged in her face; hoarse sounds came from her throat, screams held back by Egwene's hands; her heels drummed on the floor.

"stɑp ɪt, ɛɡwin!" nɪneɪiv ɡɹæbd ɛɡwinz ʃoʊldɝz, pʊlɪŋ əɹ ɔf ə ði ʌðɝ wʊmən. "ɛɡwin, stɑp ɪt! ðəɾ ɪzənt wʌt jə wɑnt!" ɹɛnə leɪ ɡɹeɪ-feɪst ən pæntɪŋ, stɛɹɪŋ waɪldli ət ðə silɪŋ.

"Stop it, Egwene!" Nynaeve grabbed Egwene's shoulders, pulling her off of the other woman. "Egwene, stop it! That isn't what you want!" Renna lay gray-faced and panting, staring wildly at the ceiling.

sʌɾənli ɛɡwin θɹu hɝsɛlf əɡɛns nɪneɪiv, sɑbɪŋ ɹæədli əɾ əɹ bɹɛst. "ʃi hɝt mi, nɪneɪiv. ʃi hɝt mi. ðeɪ ɔl dɪd. ðeɪ hɝt mi, ən hɝt mi, əntɪl aɪ dɪd wʌt ðeɪ wɑntəd. aɪ heɪt ðɛm. aɪ heɪɾ əm fəɹ hɝɾɪŋ mi, ən aɪ heɪɾ əm kəz aɪ kʊdn stɑp əm fɹəm meɪkɪŋ mi də wʌt ðeɪ wɑntəd."

Suddenly Egwene threw herself against Nynaeve, sobbing raggedly at her breast. "She hurt me, Nynaeve. She hurt me. They all did. They hurt me, and hurt me, until I did what they wanted. I hate them. I hate them for hurting me, and I hate them because I couldn't stop them from making me do what they wanted."

"aɪ noʊ," nɪneɪiv sɛd dʒɛnli. ʃi smuðd ɛɡwinz hɛɹ. "ɪɾ ɪz ɔl ɹaɪt tə heɪt ðɛm, ɛɡwin. ɪɾ ɪz. ðeɪ dɪzɝv ɪt. bʌɾ ɪɾ ɪzən ɔl ɹaɪt tə lɛɾ əm meɪk jə laɪk ðeɪ ɑɹ."

"I know," Nynaeve said gently. She smoothed Egwene's hair. "It is all right to hate them, Egwene. It is. They deserve it. But it isn't all right to let them make you like they are."

sɛɾəz hænz wɝ pɹɛs tə hɝ feɪs. ɹɛnə tʌtʃt ðə kɑlɝ əɾ əɹ θɹoʊt dɪsbɪlivɪŋli, wɪð ə ʃeɪkɪŋ hænd.

Seta's hands were pressed to her face. Renna touched the collar at her throat disbelievingly, with a shaking hand.

ɛɡwin stʃɹeɪɾənd, bɹʌʃɪŋ əɹ tɪɹz əweɪ kwɪkli. "aɪm nɑt. aɪm nɑt laɪk ðɛm." ʃi ɔlmoʊs klɔd ðə bɹeɪsləɾ ɔf ə hɝ ɹɪst ən θɹu ɪt daʊn. "aɪm nɑt. bʌɾ aɪ wɪʃ aɪ kəd kɪl ðɛm."

Egwene straightened, brushing her tears away quickly. "I'm not. I am not like them." She almost clawed the bracelet off of her wrist and threw it down. "I'm not. But I wish I could kill them."

"ðeɪ dɪzɝv ɪt." mɪn wɑz stɛɹɪŋ ɡɹɪmli ət ðə tu sʌldəm.

"They deserve it." Min was staring grimly at the two sul'dam.

"ɹænd wəd kɪl sʌmwʌn u dɪɾ ə θɪŋ laɪk ðæt," ɪleɪn sɛd. ʃi sim tə bi stilɪŋ hɝsɛlf. "aɪ æm ʃʊɹ i wʊd."

"Rand would kill someone who did a thing like that," Elayne said. She seemed to be steeling herself. "I am sure he would."

"pɝhæps ðeɪ du," nɪneɪiv sɛd, "æn pɝhæps i wʊd. bʌt mɛn ɔfən mɪsteɪk ɹivɛnʒ ən kɪlɪŋ fəɹ dʒʌstəs. ðeɪ sɛldəm əv ðə stʌmək fəɹ dʒʌstəs." ʃi hæɾ ɔfən sæɾ ɪn dʒʌdʒmənt wɪð ðə wɪmənz sɝkəl. səmtaɪmz mɛn keɪm bɪfɔɹ ðɛm, θɪŋkɪŋ wɪmən maɪt ɡɪv əm ə bɛɾɝ hɪɹɪŋ ðən ðə mɛn ə ðə vɪlədʒ kaʊnsəl, bʌt mɛn ɔlweɪz θɔt ðeɪ kəd sweɪ ðə dɪsɪʒən wɪð ɛləkwəns, əɹ pliz fəɹ mɝsi. ðə wɪmənz sɝkəl ɡeɪv mɝsi wɛɹ ɪt wɑz dɪzɝvd, bʌt dʒʌstəs ɔlweɪz, ən ɪt wɑz ðə wɪzdəm u pɹənaʊnst ɪt. ʃi pɪkt ʌp ðə bɹeɪsləɾ ɛɡwin hæd dɪskɑɹɾɪd ən kloʊzd ɪt. "aɪ wəd fɹi ɛvɹi wʊmən hɪɹ, ɪf aɪ kʊd, ən dɪstʃɹɔɪ ɛvɹi læst wʌn ə ðiz. bʌt sɪns aɪ kænɑt. . . ." ʃi slɪp ðə bɹeɪsləɾ oʊvɝ ðə seɪm pɛɡ ðət hɛl ði ʌðɝ wʌn, ðən ədʒɹɛs hɝsɛlf tə ðə sʌldəm. nɑt liʃ hoʊldɝz ɛni lɔŋɡɝ, ʃi toʊl hɝsɛlf. "pɝhæps, ɪf jə ɑɹ vɛɹi kwaɪət, jəl bi lɛft əloʊn hɪɹ lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə mænədʒ tə ɹimuv ðə kɑlɝz. ðə wil wivz əz ðə wil wɪlz, ən ɪt meɪ bi ðət juv dʌn ɪnʌf ɡʊd tə kaʊntɝbæləns ði ivəl juv dʌn, ɪnʌf ðət jəl bi əlaʊd tə ɹimuv ðɛm. ɪf nɑt, jəl bi faʊnd, ɪvɛntʃəwəli. ən aɪ θɪŋk huɛvɝ faɪnz jəl æsk ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni kwɛstʃənz bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ ɹimuv ðoʊz kɑlɝz. aɪ θɪŋk pɝhæps jəl lɝn ət fɝs hæn ðə laɪf juv ɡɪvən tə ʌðɝ wɪmən. ðəɾ ɪz dʒʌstəs," ʃi æɾəd, tə ði ʌðɝz.

"Perhaps they do," Nynaeve said, "and perhaps he would. But men often mistake revenge and killing for justice. They seldom have the stomach for justice." She had often sat in judgment with the Women's Circle. Sometimes men came before them, thinking women might give them a better hearing than the men of the Village Council, but men always thought they could sway the decision with eloquence, or pleas for mercy. The Women's Circle gave mercy where it was deserved, but justice always, and it was the Wisdom who pronounced it. She picked up the bracelet Egwene had discarded and closed it. "I would free every woman here, if I could, and destroy every last one of these. But since I cannot. . . ." She slipped the bracelet over the same peg that held the other one, then addressed herself to the sul'dam. Not Leash Holders any longer, she told herself. "Perhaps, if you are very quiet, you will be left alone here long enough to manage to remove the collars. The Wheel weaves as the Wheel wills, and it may be that you've done enough good to counterbalance the evil you have done, enough that you will be allowed to remove them. If not, you will be found, eventually. And I think whoever finds you will ask a great many questions before they remove those collars. I think perhaps you will learn at first hand the life you have given to other women. That is justice," she added, to the others.

ɹɛnə wɔɹ ə fɪkst stɛɹ ə hɔɹɝ. sɛɾəz ʃoʊldɝz ʃʊk əz ʃi sɑbd ɪndə hɝ hænz. nɪneɪiv hɑɹɾənd əɹ hɑɹt - ɪts dʒʌstəs, ʃi toʊl hɝsɛlf. ɪts - ən hɝɾɪd ði ʌðɝz aʊɾ ə ðə ɹum.

Renna wore a fixed stare of horror. Seta's shoulders shook as she sobbed into her hands. Nynaeve hardened her heart - It is justice, she told herself. It is - and herded the others out of the room.

noʊ wʌn peɪɾ ɛni mɔɹ ətɛnʃən tə ðɛm ɡoʊɪŋ aʊt ðən ðeɪ hæd kʌmɪŋ ɪn. nɪneɪiv səpoʊzd ʃi hæd ðə sʌldəm dʒɹɛs tə θæŋk fəɹ ðæt, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt weɪt tə tʃeɪnʒ ɪndə sʌmθɪŋ ɛls. ɛniθɪŋ ɛls. ðə dɝɾiəst ɹæɡ wəd fil klinɝ ɑn əɹ skɪn.

No one paid any more attention to them going out than they had coming in. Nynaeve supposed she had the sul'dam dress to thank for that, but she could not wait to change into something else. Anything else. The dirtiest rag would feel cleaner on her skin.

ðə ɡɝlz wɝ saɪlənt, wɔkɪŋ kloʊs bɪhaɪn hɝ, əntɪl ðeɪ wɝ aʊɾ ɑn ðə kɑbəlstoʊn stʃɹiɾ əɡɛn. ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ ɪf ɪt wɑz wʌt ʃi hæd dʌn əɹ ðə fɪɹ ðət sʌmwʌn maɪt stɑp ðɛm. ʃi skaʊld. wəd ðeɪv fɛl bɛɾɝ ɪf ʃi hæd lɛɾ əm wɝk ðɛmsɛlvz ʌp tə kʌɾɪŋ ðə wɪmənz θɹoʊts?

The girls were silent, walking close behind her, until they were out on the cobblestone street again. She did not know if it was what she had done or the fear that someone might stop them. She scowled. Would they have felt better if she had let them work themselves up to cutting the women's throats?

"hɔɹsəz," ɛɡwin sɛd. "wi wɪl nid hɔɹsəz. aɪ noʊ ðə steɪbəl wɛɹ ðeɪ tʊk bɛlə, bʌɾ aɪ doʊn θɪŋk wi kən ɡɛt tə hɝ."

"Horses," Egwene said. "We will need horses. I know the stable where they took Bela, but I don't think we can get to her."

"wi hæv tə liv bɛlə hɪɹ," nɪneɪiv toʊl hɝ. "wi ɑɹ livɪŋ baɪ ʃɪp."

"We have to leave Bela here," Nynaeve told her. "We are leaving by ship."

"wɛɹ ɪz ɛvɹibɑɾi?" mɪn sɛd, ən sʌɾənli nɪneɪiv ɹilaɪz ðə stʃɹit wɑz ɛmpti.

"Where is everybody?" Min said, and suddenly Nynaeve realized the street was empty.

ðə kɹaʊdz wɝ ɡɔn, nɑɾ ə saɪn ə ðɛm tə bi sin; ɛvɹi ʃɑp ən wɪndoʊ əlɔŋ ðə stʃɹit wɝ ʃʌɾɝd taɪt. bʌɾ ʌp ðə stʃɹit fɹəm ðə hɑɹbɝ keɪm ə fɔɹmeɪʃən ə sintʃæn soʊlʒɝz, ə hʌnʒɹəd əɹ mɔɹ ɪn ɔɹɾɝd ɹæŋks, wɪð ən ɔfəsɝ ət ðɛɹ hɛɾ ɪn ɪz peɪntəɾ ɑɹmɝ. ðeɪ wɝ stɪl hæfweɪ daʊn ðə stʃɹit fɹəm ðə wɪmən, bʌt ðeɪ mɑɹtʃt wɪð ə ɡɹɪm, ɪmplækəbəl stɛp, ən ɪt sim tə nɪneɪiv ðəɾ ɛvɹi aɪ wɑz fɪkst ɑn hɝ. ðæts ɹɪdɪkjələs. aɪ kæn si ðɛɹ aɪz ɪnsaɪd ðoʊz hɛlməts, ən ɪf ɛnibəɾi hæd ɡɪvən ən əlɑɹm, ɪt wəd bi bɪhaɪn ʌs. ʃi stɑpt ɛniweɪ.

The crowds were gone, not a sign of them to be seen; every shop and window along the street were shuttered tight. But up the street from the harbor came a formation of Seanchan soldiers, a hundred or more in ordered ranks, with an officer at their head in his painted armor. They were still halfway down the street from the women, but they marched with a grim, implacable step, and it seemed to Nynaeve that every eye was fixed on her. That's ridiculous. I can't see their eyes inside those helmets, and if anybody had given an alarm, it would be behind us. She stopped anyway.

"ðɛɹ ɑɹ mɔɹ bɪhaɪn ʌs," mɪn mɝmɝd. nɪneɪiv kəd hɪɹ ðoʊz buts, naʊ. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ wɪtʃ wɪl ɹitʃ əs fɝst."

"There are more behind us," Min murmured. Nynaeve could hear those boots, now. "I don't know which will reach us first."

nɪneɪiv tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. "ðeɪ ɑɹ nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ʌs." ʃi lʊk bɪɑn ði əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ soʊlʒɝz, tə ðə hɑɹbɝ, fɪld wɪð tɔl, bɑksi sintʃæn ʃɪps. ʃi kəd nɑt meɪk aʊt spɹeɪ; ʃi pɹeɪɾ ɪt wɑz stɪl ðɛɹ, ən ɹɛɾi. "wi wɪl wɔk ɹaɪt pæs ðɛm." laɪt, aɪ hoʊp wi kæn.

Nynaeve took a deep breath. "They are nothing to do with us." She looked beyond the approaching soldiers, to the harbor, filled with tall, boxy Seanchan ships. She could not make out Spray; she prayed it was still there, and ready. "We will walk right past them." Light, I hope we can.

"wʌɾ ɪf ðeɪ wɑn jə tə dʒɔɪn ðɛm, nɪneɪiv?" ɪleɪn æskt. "ju ɑɹ wɛɹɪŋ ðət dʒɹɛs. ɪf ðeɪ stɑɹɾ æskɪŋ kwɛstʃənz. . . ."

"What if they want you to join them, Nynaeve?" Elayne asked. "You are wearing that dress. If they start asking questions. . . ."

"aɪ wɪl nɑt ɡoʊ bæk," ɛɡwin sɛd ɡɹɪmli. "aɪl daɪ fɝst. lemi ʃoʊ ðɛm wʌt ðeɪv tɔt mi." tə nɪneɪivz aɪ, ə ɡoʊldən nɪmbəs sʌɾənli sim tə sɝaʊn hɝ.

"I will not go back," Egwene said grimly. "I'll die first. Let me show them what they've taught me." To Nynaeve's eye, a golden nimbus suddenly seemed to surround her.

"noʊ!" ʃi sɛd, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz tu leɪt.

"No!" she said, but it was too late.

wɪð ə ɹɔɹ laɪk θʌndɝ, ðə stʃɹiɾ ʌndɝ ðə fɝst ɹæŋks ə sintʃæn ɪɹʌptəd, dɝɾ ən kɑbəlstoʊnz ən ɑɹmɝd mɛn θɹoʊn əsaɪd laɪk spɹeɪ fɹəm ə faʊntən. stɪl ɡloʊɪŋ, ɛɡwin spʌn tə stɛɹ ʌp ðə stʃɹit, ən ðə θʌndɝəs ɹɔɹ wɑz ɹɪpiɾɪd. dɝt ɹeɪn daʊn ɑn ðə wɪmən. ʃaʊɾɪŋ sintʃæn soʊlʒɝz skæɾɝd ɪn ɡʊɾ ɔɹɾɝ tə ʃɛltɝ ɪn æliz ən bɪhaɪn stups. ɪn moʊməns ðeɪ wɝ ɔl aʊɾ ə saɪt, ɪksɛp fəɹ ðoʊz u leɪ ɝaʊn ðə tu lɑɹdʒ hoʊlz mɑɹɪŋ ðə stʃɹit. səm ə ðoʊz stɝd fibli, ən moʊnz dʒɹɪftəɾ əlɔŋ ðə stʃɹit.

With a roar like thunder, the street under the first ranks of Seanchan erupted, dirt and cobblestones and armored men thrown aside like spray from a fountain. Still glowing, Egwene spun to stare up the street, and the thunderous roar was repeated. Dirt rained down on the women. Shouting Seanchan soldiers scattered in good order to shelter in alleys and behind stoops. In moments they were all out of sight, except for those who lay around the two large holes marring the street. Some of those stirred feebly, and moans drifted along the street.

nɪneɪiv θɹu ʌp əɹ hænz, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lʊk ɪn boʊθ dɝɛkʃənz ət wʌns. "ju ful! wəɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑt tə ətʃɹækt ətɛnʃən!" ðəɹ wɑz noʊ hoʊp ə ðət naʊ. ʃi oʊnli hoʊp ðeɪ kəd mænədʒ tə wɝk ðɛɹ weɪ ɝaʊn ðə soʊlʒɝz tə ðə hɑɹbɝ θɹu ði æliz. ðə deɪmeɪn mʌs noʊ, tu, naʊ. ðeɪ kəd nɑɾ əv mɪs ðæt.

Nynaeve threw up her hands, trying to look in both directions at once. "You fool! We are trying not to attract attention!" There was no hope of that now. She only hoped they could manage to work their way around the soldiers to the harbor through the alleys. The damane must know, too, now. They could not have missed that.

"aɪ woʊnt ɡoʊ bæk tə ðət kɑlɝ," ɛɡwin sɛd fɪɹsli. "aɪ woʊnt!"

"I won't go back to that collar," Egwene said fiercely. "I won't!"

"lʊk aʊt!" mɪn ʃaʊɾəd.

"Look out!" Min shouted.

wɪð ə ʃɹɪl waɪn, ə faɪɝbɔl əz bɪɡ əz ə hɔɹs ɑɹtʃt ɪndə ði ɛɹ oʊvɝ ðə ɹuftɑps ən bɪɡæn tə fɔl. dɝɛkli təwɔɹd ðɛm.

With a shrill whine, a fireball as big as a horse arched into the air over the rooftops and began to fall. Directly toward them.

"ɹʌn!" nɪneɪiv ʃaʊɾəd, ən θɹu hɝsɛlf ɪndə ə daɪv təwɔɹd ðə nɪɹəst æliweɪ, bɪtwin tu ʃʌɾɝd ʃɑps.

"Run!" Nynaeve shouted, and threw herself into a dive toward the nearest alleyway, between two shuttered shops.

ʃi lændəɾ ɔkwɝdli ɑn əɹ stʌmək wɪð ə ɡɹʌnt, luzɪŋ hæf əɹ bɹɛθ, əz ðə faɪɝbɔl stʃɹʌk. hɑt wɪnd wɑʃt oʊvɝ əɹ daʊn ðə nɛɹoʊ pæsədʒ. ɡʌlpɪŋ ɛɹ, ʃi ɹoʊld ɑntu hɝ bæk ən stɛɹd bæk ɪndə ðə stʃɹit.

She landed awkwardly on her stomach with a grunt, losing half her breath, as the fireball struck. Hot wind washed over her down the narrow passage. Gulping air, she rolled onto her back and stared back into the street.

ðə kɑbəlstoʊnz wɛɹ ðeɪ hæd bɪn stændɪŋ wɝ tʃɪpt ən kɹækt ən blækən ɪn ə sɝkəl tɛn peɪsɪz əkɹɔs. ɪleɪn wɑz kɹaʊtʃt dʒʌst ɪnsaɪɾ ənʌðɝ æli ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə stʃɹit. ʌv mɪn ən ɛɡwin, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ saɪn. nɪneɪiv klæpt ə hæn tə hɝ maʊθ ɪn hɔɹɝ.

The cobblestones where they had been standing were chipped and cracked and blackened in a circle ten paces across. Elayne was crouched just inside another alley on the other side of the street. Of Min and Egwene, there was no sign. Nynaeve clapped a hand to her mouth in horror.

ɪleɪn sim tə ʌndɝstænd wʌt ʃi wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ. ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ʃʊk əɹ hɛd vaɪələnli ən pɔɪntəd daʊn ðə stʃɹit. ðeɪ hæd ɡɔn ðət weɪ.

Elayne seemed to understand what she was thinking. The Daughter-Heir shook her head violently and pointed down the street. They had gone that way.

nɪneɪiv hivd ə saɪ ʌv ɹɪlif ðəɾ ɪmiɾiətli tɝn tə ə ɡɹaʊl. ful ɡɝl! wi cʊɾə ɡɑɾən baɪ ðɛm! ðəɹ wɑz noʊ taɪm fəɹ ɹɪkɹɪmɪneɪʃənz, ðoʊ. ʃi skuɾɪd tə ðə kɔɹnɝ ən pɪɹd kɔʃəsli ɝaʊn ði ɛdʒ ə ðə bɪldɪŋ.

Nynaeve heaved a sigh of relief that immediately turned to a growl. Fool girl! We could have gotten by them! There was no time for recriminations, though. She scooted to the corner and peered cautiously around the edge of the building.

ə hɛd-saɪz faɪɝbɔl flæʃt daʊn ðə stʃɹit təwɔɹd hɝ. ʃi lɛp bæk dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ ɪɾ ɪksploʊɾəd əɡɛns ðə kɔɹnɝ wɛɹ əɹ oʊn hɛd hæd bɪn, ʃaʊɝɪŋ əɹ wɪð stoʊn tʃɪps.

A head-sized fireball flashed down the street toward her. She leaped back just before it exploded against the corner where her own head had been, showering her with stone chips.

æŋɡɝ hæɾ əɹ əwɑʃ ɪn ðə wʌn paʊɝ bɪfɔɹ ʃi wɑz əwɛɹ ʌv ɪt. laɪtnɪŋ flæʃt aʊɾ ə ðə skaɪ, stʃɹaɪkɪŋ sʌmwɛɹ ʌp ðə stʃɹit wɪð ə kɹæʃ nɪɹ ði ɔɹədʒən ə ðə faɪɝbɔl. ənʌðɝ dʒæɡd boʊl splɪt ðə skaɪ, ən ðən ʃi wɑz ɹʌnɪŋ daʊn ði æli. bɪhaɪn hɝ, laɪtnɪŋ læns ðə maʊθ ə ði æli.

Anger had her awash in the One Power before she was aware of it. Lightning flashed out of the sky, striking somewhere up the street with a crash near the origin of the fireball. Another jagged bolt split the sky, and then she was running down the alley. Behind her, lightning lanced the mouth of the alley.

ɪf doʊmən dʌzn əv ðət ʃɪp weɪɾɪŋ, aɪl. . . . laɪt, lɛɾ əs ɔl ɹitʃ ɪt seɪfli.

If Domon doesn't have that ship waiting, I'll. . . . Light, let us all reach it safely.

beɪl doʊmən dʒɝkt ɪɹɛkt əz laɪtnɪŋ stʃɹikt əkɹɔs ðə sleɪt-ɡɹeɪ skaɪ, stʃɹaɪkɪŋ sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ðə taʊn, ðən əɡɛn. ðəɹ də noʊ bi ɪnʌf klaʊdz fəɹ ðæt!

Bayle Domon jerked erect as lightning streaked across the slate-gray sky, striking somewhere in the town, then again. There do no be enough clouds for that!

sʌmθɪŋ ɹʌmbəld laʊdli ʌp ɪn ðə taʊn, ən ə bɔl ə faɪɝ smæʃt ɪndə ə ɹuftɑp dʒʌst əbʌv ðə dɑks, θɹoʊɪŋ splɪntɝd sleɪts ɪn waɪɾ ɑɹks. ðə dɑks hæɾ ɛmptid ðɛmsɛlvz ə pipəl ə waɪl bæk, ɪksɛp fəɹ ə fju sintʃæn; ðeɪ ɹæn waɪldli, naʊ, dʒɹɔɪŋ sɔɹdz ən ʃaʊɾɪŋ. ə mæn əpɪɹd fɹəm wʌn ə ðə wɛɹhaʊzɪz wɪð ə ɡɹoʊm əɾ ɪz saɪd, ɹʌnɪŋ tə kip ʌp wɪð ðə bists lɔŋ lips əz ðeɪ vænɪʃt ɪndə wʌn ə ðə stʃɹits liɾɪŋ ʌp fɹəm ðə wɔɾɝ.

Something rumbled loudly up in the town, and a ball of fire smashed into a rooftop just above the docks, throwing splintered slates in wide arcs. The docks had emptied themselves of people a while back, except for a few Seanchan; they ran wildly, now, drawing swords and shouting. A man appeared from one of the warehouses with a grolm at his side, running to keep up with the beast's long leaps as they vanished into one of the streets leading up from the water.

wʌn ə doʊmənz kɹumɪn dʒʌmp fəɹ ən æks ən swʌŋ ɪt haɪ oʊvɝ ə mʊɹɪŋ keɪbəl.

One of Domon's crewmen jumped for an axe and swung it high over a mooring cable.

ɪn tu stʃɹaɪdz, doʊmən siz ði əpɹeɪzd æks wɪð wʌn hæn ən ðə mænz θɹoʊt wɪð ði ʌðɝ. "spɹeɪ də steɪ tɪl aɪ də seɪ seɪl, æɛdwɪn koʊl!"

In two strides, Domon seized the upraised axe with one hand and the man's throat with the other. "Spray do stay till I do say sail, Aedwin Cole!"

"ðeɪɹ ɡoʊɪŋ mæd, kæptən!" jɑɹən ʃaʊɾəd. ən ɪksploʊʒən sɛn ɛkoʊz ɹʌmbəlɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə hɑɹbɝ, sɛndɪŋ ðə ɡʌlz ɪndə skɹimɪŋ sɝkəlz, ən laɪtnɪŋ flɪkɝɾ əɡɛn, kɹæʃɪŋ tə ɝθ ɪnsaɪd fɑlm. "ðə deɪmeɪn wɪl kɪl əs ɔl! lɛɾ əs ɡoʊ waɪl ðəɹ bɪzi kɪlɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝ. ðəl nɛvɝ noʊɾəs əs tɪl wəɹ ɡɔn!"

"They're going mad, Captain!" Yarin shouted. An explosion sent echoes rumbling across the harbor, sending the gulls into screaming circles, and lightning flickered again, crashing to earth inside Falme. "The damane will kill us all! Let us go while they're busy killing one another. They will never notice us till we are gone!"

"aɪ dɪd ɡɪv maɪ wɝd," doʊmən sɛd. hi ɹɛntʃt ði æks fɹəm koʊlz hæn ən θɹu ɪt klæɾɝɪŋ ɑntu ðə dɛk. "aɪ dɪd ɡɪv maɪ wɝd." hɝi, wʊmən, hi θɔt, ɛɛs sədaɪ əɹ wʌtɛvɝ jə bi. hɝi!

"I did give my word," Domon said. He wrenched the axe from Cole's hand and threw it clattering onto the deck. "I did give my word." Hurry, woman, he thought, Aes Sedai or whatever you be. Hurry!

dʒɛəfɹæm bɔɹnhəld aɪd ðə laɪtnɪŋ flæʃɪŋ oʊvɝ fɑlm ən dɪsmɪst ɪt fɹəm ɪz maɪnd. səm hjudʒ flaɪɪŋ kɹitʃɝ - wʌn ə ðə sintʃæn mɑnstɝz, noʊ daʊt - flu waɪldli tə ɪskeɪp ðə boʊls. ɪf ðəɹ wɑz ə stɔɹm, ɪt wəd hɪndɝ ðə sintʃæn əz mʌtʃ əz ɪt dɪd hɪm. nɪɹli tʃɹiləs hɪlz, ə fju tɑp baɪ spɑɹs θɪkəts, stɪl hɪd ðə taʊn fɹəm hɪm, ən ɪm fɹəm ɪt.

Geofram Bornhald eyed the lightning flashing over Falme and dismissed it from his mind. Some huge flying creature - one of the Seanchan monsters, no doubt - flew wildly to escape the bolts. If there was a storm, it would hinder the Seanchan as much as it did him. Nearly treeless hills, a few topped by sparse thickets, still hid the town from him, and him from it.

hɪz θaʊzən mɛn leɪ spɹɛɾ aʊt tə iðɝ saɪɾ ə hɪm, wʌn lɔŋ, maʊntəd ɹæŋk ɹɪpəlɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə hɑloʊz bɪtwin hɪlz. ðə koʊld wɪn tɔs ðɛɹ waɪt kloʊks ən flæp ðə bænɝ ət bɔɹnhəlz saɪd, ðə weɪvi-ɹeɪd ɡoʊldən sʌn ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt.

His thousand men lay spread out to either side of him, one long, mounted rank rippling along the hollows between hills. The cold wind tossed their white cloaks and flapped the banner at Bornhald's side, the wavy-rayed golden sun of the Children of the Light.

"ɡoʊ naʊ, baɪɑɝ," hi kəmændəd. ðə ɡɔnt-feɪs mæn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ən bɔɹnhəl pʊɾ ə snæp ɪndə hɪz vɔɪs. "aɪ sɛd, ɡoʊ, tʃaɪl baɪɑɝ!"

"Go now, Byar," he commanded. The gaunt-faced man hesitated, and Bornhald put a snap into his voice. "I said, go, Child Byar!"

baɪɑɝ tʌtʃt hæn tə hɑɹɾ ən baʊd. "æz jə kəmænd, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən." hi tɝn ɪz hɔɹs əweɪ, ɛvɹi laɪn ə hɪm ʃaʊɾɪŋ ɹɪlʌktəns.

Byar touched hand to heart and bowed. "As you command, my Lord Captain." He turned his horse away, every line of him shouting reluctance.

bɔɹnhəl pʊt baɪɑɝ aʊɾ ə hɪz maɪnd. hi hæd dʌn wʌɾ i kʊd, ðɛɹ. hi ɹeɪzd ɪz vɔɪs. "ðə lidʒən wɪl ədvæns əɾ ə wɔk!"

Bornhald put Byar out of his mind. He had done what he could, there. He raised his voice. "The legion will advance at a walk!"

wɪð ə kɹik ə sæɾəlz ðə lɔŋ laɪn ʌv waɪt-kloʊk mɛn muv sloʊli təwɔɹd fɑlm.

With a creak of saddles the long line of white-cloaked men moved slowly toward Falme.

ɹænd pɪɹɾ ɝaʊn ðə kɔɹnɝ ət ði əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ sintʃæn, ðən dʌk bæk ɪndə ðə nɛɹoʊ æli bɪtwin tu steɪbəlz wɪð ə ɡɹɪmɑs. ðeɪ wəd bi ðəɹ sun. ðəɹ wɑz blʌd kɹʌstɪɾ ɑn ɪz tʃik. ðə kʌts i hæd fɹəm tʃɹɑk bɝnd, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə bi dʌn fəɹ əm naʊ. laɪtnɪŋ flæʃt əkɹɔs ðə skaɪ əɡɛn; hi fɛl ðə ɹʌmbəl ʌv ɪts plʌmət θɹu hɪz buts. wʌɾ ɪn ðə neɪm ə ðə laɪɾ ɪz hæpənɪŋ?

Rand peered around the corner at the approaching Seanchan, then ducked back into the narrow alley between two stables with a grimace. They would be there soon. There was blood crusted on his cheek. The cuts he had from Turak burned, but there was nothing to be done for them now. Lightning flashed across the sky again; he felt the rumble of its plummet through his boots. What in the name of the Light is happening?

"kloʊs?" ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd. "ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ mʌs bi seɪvd, ɹænd." dɪspaɪt ðə sintʃæn, dɪspaɪt ðə laɪtnɪŋ ən stʃɹeɪnʒ ɪksploʊʒənz daʊn ɪn ðə taʊn pɹɑpɝ, hi sim pɹiɑkjəpaɪd wɪð ɪz oʊn θɔts. mæt ən pɛɹɪn ən hʊɹɪn wɝ daʊn ət ði ʌðɝ ɛn ə ði æli, wɑtʃɪŋ ənʌðɝ sintʃæn pətʃɹoʊl. ðə pleɪs wɛɹ ðeɪ hæd lɛf ðə hɔɹsəz wɑz kloʊs, naʊ, ɪf ðeɪ kəɾ oʊnli ɹitʃ ɪt.

"Close?" Ingtar said. "The Horn of Valere must be saved, Rand." Despite the Seanchan, despite the lightning and strange explosions down in the town proper, he seemed preoccupied with his own thoughts. Mat and Perrin and Hurin were down at the other end of the alley, watching another Seanchan patrol. The place where they had left the horses was close, now, if they could only reach it.

"ʃiz ɪn tʃɹʌbəl," ɹænd mʌɾɝd. ɛɡwin. ðəɹ wɑz ən ɑd filɪŋ ɪn ɪz hɛd, əz ɪf pisəz ə hɪz laɪf wɝ ɪn deɪnʒɝ. ɛɡwin wɑz wʌn pis, wʌn θɹɛɾ ə ðə kɔɹd ðət meɪɾ ɪz laɪf, bʌt ðəɹ wɝ ʌðɝz, ən i kəd fil əm θɹɛɾənd. daʊn ðɛɹ, ɪn fɑlm. ən ɪf ɛni ʌv ðoʊz θɹɛdz wɑz dɪstʃɹɔɪd, hɪz laɪf wəd nɛvɝ bi kəmplit, ðə weɪ ɪt wɑz mɛn tə bi. hi dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ɪt, bʌt ðə filɪŋ wɑz ʃʊɹ ən sɝɾən.

"She's in trouble," Rand muttered. Egwene. There was an odd feeling in his head, as if pieces of his life were in danger. Egwene was one piece, one thread of the cord that made his life, but there were others, and he could feel them threatened. Down there, in Falme. And if any of those threads was destroyed, his life would never be complete, the way it was meant to be. He did not understand it, but the feeling was sure and certain.

"wʌn mæn kəd hoʊl fɪfti hɪɹ," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd. ðə tu steɪbəlz stʊd kloʊs təɡɛðɝ, wɪð bɛɹli ɹum fəɹ ðə pɛɹ ə ðɛm tə stæn saɪd baɪ saɪd bɪtwin ðɛm. "wʌn mæn hoʊldɪŋ fɪfti əɾ ə nɛɹoʊ pæsədʒ. nɑɾ ə bæd weɪ tə daɪ. sɔŋz əv bɪn meɪɾ əbaʊt lɛs."

"One man could hold fifty here," Ingtar said. The two stables stood close together, with barely room for the pair of them to stand side by side between them. "One man holding fifty at a narrow passage. Not a bad way to die. Songs have been made about less."

"ðɛɹz noʊ nid fəɹ ðæt," ɹænd sɛd. "aɪ hoʊp." ə ɹuftɑp ɪn ðə taʊn ɪksploʊɾəd. haʊ æm aɪ gɑnə ɡɛt bæk ɪn hɪɹ? aɪ hæv tə ɹitʃ hɝ. ɹitʃ ðɛm? ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd, hi pikt ɝaʊn ðə kɔɹnɝ əɡɛn. ðə sintʃæn wɝ kloʊsɝ, stɪl kʌmɪŋ.

"There's no need for that," Rand said. "I hope." A rooftop in the town exploded. How am I going to get back in here? I have to reach her. Reach them? Shaking his head, he peeked around the corner again. The Seanchan were closer, still coming.

"aɪ nɛvɝ nu wʌɾ i wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə du," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd sɔfli, əz ɪf tɔkɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf. hi hæɾ ɪz sɔɹɾ aʊt, tɛstɪŋ ði ɛdʒ wɪð ɪz θʌm. "ə peɪl lɪɾəl mæn jə dɪdn sim tə ɹɪli noʊɾəs ivən wən jə wɝ lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm. teɪk ɪm ɪnsaɪd fæl dæɹə, aɪ wɑz toʊld, ɪnsaɪd ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs. aɪ dɪd nɑt wɑn tə, bʌɾ aɪ hæd tə də ɪt. jə ʌndɝstænd? aɪ hæd tə. aɪ nɛvɝ nu wʌɾ i ɪntɛndəɾ əntɪl i ʃɑt ðəɾ æɹoʊ. aɪ stɪl doʊnt noʊ ɪf ɪt wɑz mɛn fəɹ ði æmɪɝlɪn, əɹ fəɹ ju."

"I never knew what he was going to do," Ingtar said softly, as if talking to himself. He had his sword out, testing the edge with his thumb. "A pale little man you didn't seem to really notice even when you were looking at him. Take him inside Fal Dara, I was told, inside the fortress. I did not want to, but I had to do it. You understand? I had to. I never knew what he intended until he shot that arrow. I still don't know if it was meant for the Amyrlin, or for you."

ɹænd fɛlt ə tʃɪl. hi stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪŋtʃɹ. "wʌɾ ɑɹ jə seɪɪŋ?" hi wɪspɝd.

Rand felt a chill. He stared at Ingtar. "What are you saying?" he whispered.

stʌɾiɪŋ ɪz bleɪd, ɪŋtʃɹ dɪd nɑt sim tə hɪɹ. "hjumənkaɪn ɪz biɪŋ swɛpt əweɪ ɛvɹiwɛɹ. neɪʃənz feɪl ən vænɪʃ. dɑɹkfɹɛnz ɑɹ ɛvɹiwɛɹ, ən nʌn ə ðiz saʊθlændɝz sim tə noʊɾəs əɹ kɛɹ. wi faɪt tə hoʊl ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz, tə kip əm seɪf ɪn ðɛɹ haʊsəz, ən ɛvɹi jɪɹ, dɪspaɪɾ ɔl wi kən du, ðə blaɪɾ ədvænsəz. ən ðiz saʊθlændɝz θɪŋk tʃɹɑləks ɑɹ mɪθs, ən mɹdʒɹɑl ə ɡlimənz teɪl." hi fɹaʊn ən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ɪt sim ði oʊnli weɪ. wi wəd bi dɪstʃɹɔɪd fəɹ nʌθɪŋ, dɪfɛndɪŋ pipəl u də nɑɾ ivən noʊ, əɹ kɛɹ. ɪt sim lɑdʒɪkəl. waɪ ʃəd wi bi dɪstʃɹɔɪd fəɹ ðɛm, wən wi kəd meɪk əɹ oʊn pis? bɛɾɝ ðə ʃædoʊ, aɪ θɔt, ðən jusləs əblɪviən, laɪk kæɹələn, əɹ hɑɹɾən, ɔɹ. . . . ɪt sim soʊ lɑdʒɪkəl, ðɛn."

Studying his blade, Ingtar did not seem to hear. "Humankind is being swept away everywhere. Nations fail and vanish. Darkfriends are everywhere, and none of these southlanders seem to notice or care. We fight to hold the Borderlands, to keep them safe in their houses, and every year, despite all we can do, the Blight advances. And these southlanders think Trollocs are myths, and Myrddraal a gleeman's tale." He frowned and shook his head. "It seemed the only way. We would be destroyed for nothing, defending people who do not even know, or care. It seemed logical. Why should we be destroyed for them, when we could make our own peace? Better the Shadow, I thought, than useless oblivion, like Caralain, or Hardan, or. . . . It seemed so logical, then."

ɹænd ɡɹæbd ɪŋtʃɹz ləpɛlz. "ju ɑɹən meɪkɪŋ ɛni sɛns." hi kæn min wʌt hiz seɪɪŋ. hi kænt. "seɪ ɪt pleɪn, wʌtɛvɝ jə min. jə ɑɹ tɔkɪŋ kɹeɪzi!"

Rand grabbed Ingtar's lapels. "You aren't making any sense." He can't mean what he's saying. He can't. "Say it plain, whatever you mean. You are talking crazy!"

fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm ɪŋtʃɹ lʊkt ət ɹænd. hɪz aɪz ʃoʊn wɪð ənʃt tɪɹz. "ju ɑɹ ə bɛɾɝ mæn ðən aɪ. ʃɛpɝɾ əɹ lɔɹd, ə bɛɾɝ mæn. ðə pɹɑfəsi sɛz, 'lɛɾ u saʊnz mi θɪŋk nɑɾ ʌv ɡlɔɹi, bʌɾ oʊnli sælveɪʃən.' ɪt wɑz maɪ sælveɪʃən aɪ wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv. aɪ wəd saʊn ðə hɔɹn, ən lɛd ðə hɪɹoʊz ə ði eɪdʒəz əɡɛnst ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl. ʃʊɹli ðət wʊɾə bɪn ɪnʌf tə seɪv mi. noʊ mæn kən wɔk soʊ lɔŋ ɪn ðə ʃædoʊ ðəɾ i kænɑt kʌm əɡɛn tə ðə laɪt. ðəɾ ɪz wʌt ðeɪ seɪ. ʃʊɹli ðət wʊɾə bɪn ɪnʌf tə wɑʃ əweɪ wʌɾ aɪ hæv bɪn, ən dʌn."

For the first time Ingtar looked at Rand. His eyes shone with unshed tears. "You are a better man than I. Shepherd or lord, a better man. The prophecy says, 'Let who sounds me think not of glory, but only salvation.' It was my salvation I was thinking of. I would sound the Horn, and lead the heroes of the Ages against Shayol Ghul. Surely that would have been enough to save me. No man can walk so long in the Shadow that he cannot come again to the Light. That is what they say. Surely that would have been enough to wash away what I have been, and done."

"oʊ, laɪt, ɪŋtʃɹ." ɹænd ɹilist ɪz hoʊld ɑn ði ʌðɝ mæn ən sæɡd bæk əɡɛns ðə steɪbəl wɔl. "aɪ θɪŋk. . . . aɪ θɪŋk wɑntɪŋ tə ɪz ɪnʌf. aɪ θɪŋk ɔl juv tə də ɪz stɑp biɪŋ . . . wʌn ə ðɛm." ɪŋtʃɹ flɪntʃt əz ɪf ɹænd hæd sɛɾ ɪɾ aʊt laʊd. dɑɹkfɹɛnd.

"Oh, Light, Ingtar." Rand released his hold on the other man and sagged back against the stable wall. "I think. . . . I think wanting to is enough. I think all you have to do is stop being . . . one of them." Ingtar flinched as if Rand had said it out loud. Darkfriend.

"ɹænd, wən vɛɹɪn bɹɔɾ əs hɪɹ wɪð ðə pɔɹɾəl stoʊn, aɪ - aɪ lɪvd ʌðɝ laɪvz. səmtaɪmz aɪ hɛl ðə hɔɹn, bʌɾ aɪ nɛvɝ saʊndəɾ ɪt. aɪ tʃɹaɪd tə ɪskeɪp wʌɾ aɪd bɪkʌm, bʌɾ aɪ nɛvɝ dɪd. ɔlweɪz ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɛls ɹikwaɪɝɾ ə mi, ɔlweɪz sʌmθɪŋ wɝs ðən ðə læst, əntɪl aɪ wɑz. . . . jə wɝ ɹɛɾi tə ɡɪv ɪɾ ʌp tə seɪv ə fɹɛnd. θɪŋk nɑɾ ʌv ɡlɔɹi. oʊ, laɪt, hɛlp mi."

"Rand, when Verin brought us here with the Portal Stone, I - I lived other lives. Sometimes I held the Horn, but I never sounded it. I tried to escape what I'd become, but I never did. Always there was something else required of me, always something worse than the last, until I was. . . . You were ready to give it up to save a friend. Think not of glory. Oh, Light, help me."

ɹænd dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt tə seɪ. ɪt wɑz əz ɪf ɛɡwin hæd toʊld ɪm ʃi hæd mɝɾɝd tʃɪlʒɹən. tu hɔɹəbəl tə bi bɪlivd. tu hɔɹəbəl fəɹ ɛniwʌn tə ədmɪt tə ənlɛs ɪt wɑz tʃɹu. tu hɔɹəbəl.

Rand did not know what to say. It was as if Egwene had told him she had murdered children. Too horrible to be believed. Too horrible for anyone to admit to unless it was true. Too horrible.

æftɝ ə taɪm, ɪŋtʃɹ spoʊk əɡɛn, fɝmli. "ðɛɹ əz tə bi ə pɹaɪs, ɹænd. ðəɹ ɪz ɔlweɪz ə pɹaɪs. pɝhæps aɪ kən peɪ ɪt hɪɹ."

After a time, Ingtar spoke again, firmly. "There has to be a price, Rand. There is always a price. Perhaps I can pay it here."

"ɪŋtʃɹ, aɪ - "

"Ingtar, I - "

"ɪɾ ɪz ɛvɹi mænz ɹaɪt, ɹænd, tə tʃuz wən tə ʃið ðə sɔɹd. ivən wʌn laɪk mi."

"It is every man's right, Rand, to choose when to Sheathe the Sword. Even one like me."

bɪfɔɹ ɹænd kəd seɪ ɛniθɪŋ, hʊɹɪn keɪm ɹʌnɪŋ daʊn ði æli. "ðə pətʃɹoʊl tɝn əsaɪd," hi sɛd hɝidli, "daʊn ɪndə ðə taʊn. ðeɪ sim tə bi ɡæðɝɪŋ daʊn ðɛɹ. mæt ən pɛɹɪn wɛn ɑn." hi tʊk ə kwɪk lʊk daʊn ðə stʃɹiɾ ən pʊl bæk. "wid bɛɾɝ də ðə seɪm, lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹ, lɔɹd ɹænd. ðoʊz bʌɡ-hɛɾəd sintʃæn ɑɹ ɔlmoʊs hɪɹ."

Before Rand could say anything, Hurin came running down the alley. "The patrol turned aside," he said hurriedly, "down into the town. They seem to be gathering down there. Mat and Perrin went on."
