He took a quick look down the street and pulled back. "We'd better do the same, Lord Ingtar, Lord Rand. Those bug-headed Seanchan are almost here."

"ɡoʊ, ɹænd," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd. hi tɝn tə feɪs ðə stʃɹiɾ ən dɪd nɑt lʊk ət ɹænd əɹ hʊɹɪn əɡɛn. "teɪk ðə hɔɹn wɛɹ ɪt bɪlɔŋz. aɪ ɔlweɪz nu ði æmɪɝlɪn ʃʊɾə ɡɪvən jə ðə tʃɑɹdʒ. bʌɾ ɔl aɪ ɛvɝ wɑntəd wɑz tə kip ʃaɪnɝ hoʊl, tə kip əs fɹəm biɪŋ swɛpt əweɪ ən fɝɡɑɾən."

"Go, Rand," Ingtar said. He turned to face the street and did not look at Rand or Hurin again. "Take the Horn where it belongs. I always knew the Amyrlin should have given you the charge. But all I ever wanted was to keep Shienar whole, to keep us from being swept away and forgotten."

"aɪ noʊ, ɪŋtʃɹ." ɹænd dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ. "ðə laɪt ʃaɪn ɑn ju, lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹ ə haʊs ʃɪnoʊwə, ən meɪ jə ʃɛltɝ ɪn ðə pɑm ə ðə kɹieɪɾɝz hænd." hi tʌtʃt ɪŋtʃɹz ʃoʊldɝ. "ðə læst ɛmbɹeɪs ə ðə mʌðɝ wɛlkəm jə hoʊm." hʊɹɪn ɡæspt.

"I know, Ingtar." Rand drew a deep breath. "The Light shine on you, Lord Ingtar of House Shinowa, and may you shelter in the palm of the Creator's hand." He touched Ingtar's shoulder. "The last embrace of the mother welcome you home." Hurin gasped.

"θæŋk ju," ɪŋtʃɹ sɛd sɔfli. ə tɛnʃən sim tə ɡoʊ aʊɾ ə hɪm. fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm sɪns ðə naɪɾ ə ðə tʃɹɑlɑk ɹeɪɾ ɑn fæl dæɹə, hi stʊɾ əz i hæd wən ɹænd fɝst sɔ hɪm, kɑnfəɾənt ən ɹɪlækst. kɑntɛnt.

"Thank you," Ingtar said softly. A tension seemed to go out of him. For the first time since the night of the Trolloc raid on Fal Dara, he stood as he had when Rand first saw him, confident and relaxed. Content.

ɹænd tɝn ən faʊn hʊɹɪn stɛɹɪŋ ət hɪm, stɛɹɪŋ ət boʊθ ə ðɛm. "ɪɾ ɪz taɪm fəɹ əs tə ɡoʊ."

Rand turned and found Hurin staring at him, staring at both of them. "It is time for us to go."

"bʌt lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹ - "

"But Lord Ingtar - "

" - dʌz wʌt hiz tə," ɹænd sɛd ʃɑɹpli. "bʌt wi ɡoʊ." hʊɹɪn nɑɾəd, ən ɹænd tʃɹɑɾəd æftɝ hɪm. ɹænd kəd hɪɹ ðə stɛɾi tʃɹɛɾ ə ðə sintʃænz buts, naʊ. hi dɪd nɑt lʊk bæk.

" - does what he has to," Rand said sharply. "But we go." Hurin nodded, and Rand trotted after him. Rand could hear the steady tread of the Seanchan's boots, now. He did not look back.


tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾisɛvən


CHAPTER 47

ðə ɡɹeɪv ɪz noʊ bɑɹ tə maɪ kɔl


The Grave Is No Bar to My Call

mæt ən pɛɹɪn wɝ maʊntəd baɪ ðə taɪm ɹænd ən hʊɹɪn ɹitʃt ðɛm. fɑɹ bɪhaɪn hɪm, ɹænd hɝɾ ɪŋtʃɹz vɔɪs ɹaɪz. "ðə laɪt, ən ʃɪnoʊwə!" ðə klæʃ ə stil dʒɔɪn ðə ɹɔɹ ʌv ʌðɝ vɔɪsəz.

Mat and Perrin were mounted by the time Rand and Hurin reached them. Far behind him, Rand heard Ingtar's voice rise. "The Light, and Shinowa!" The clash of steel joined the roar of other voices.

"wɛɹz ɪŋtʃɹ?" mæt ʃaʊɾəd. "wʌts ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn?" hi hæd ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ læʃt tə ðə haɪ pɑməl ə hɪz sæɾəl əz ɪf ɪt wɝ dʒʌst ɛni hɔɹn, bʌt ðə dæɡɝ wɑz ɪn ɪz bɛlt, ðə ɹubi-tɪp hɪl kʌpt pɹoʊtɛktɪvli ɪn ə peɪl hæn ðət simd meɪɾ ə nʌθɪŋ bʌt boʊn ən sɪnu.

"Where's Ingtar?" Mat shouted. "What's going on?" He had the Horn of Valere lashed to the high pommel of his saddle as if it were just any horn, but the dagger was in his belt, the ruby-tipped hilt cupped protectively in a pale hand that seemed made of nothing but bone and sinew.

"hiz daɪɪŋ," ɹænd sɛd hɑɹʃli əz i swʌŋ ɑntu ɹɛdz bæk.

"He's dying," Rand said harshly as he swung onto Red's back.

"ðɛn wɪv tə hɛlp hɪm," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "mæt kən teɪk ðə hɔɹn ən ðə dæɡɝ ɑn tə - "

"Then we have to help him," Perrin said. "Mat can take the Horn and the dagger on to - "

"hi ɪz duɪŋ ɪt soʊ wi kən ɔl ɡɛɾ əweɪ," ɹænd sɛd. fəɹ ðæt, tu. "wi wɪl ɔl teɪk ðə hɔɹn tə vɛɹɪn, ən ðən jə kən hɛlp əɹ teɪk ɪt wɛɹɛvɝ ʃi sɛz ɪt bɪlɔŋz."

"He is doing it so we can all get away," Rand said. For that, too. "We will all take the Horn to Verin, and then you can help her take it wherever she says it belongs."

"wʌt dʒju min?" pɛɹɪn æskt. ɹænd dʌɡ hɪz hilz ɪndə ðə beɪz flæŋks, ən ɹɛd lɛpt əweɪ təwɔɹd ðə hɪlz bɪɑn ðə taʊn.

"What do you mean?" Perrin asked. Rand dug his heels into the bay's flanks, and Red leaped away toward the hills beyond the town.

"ðə laɪt, ən ʃɪnoʊwə!" ɪŋtʃɹz ʃaʊt sɔɹɾ æftɝ hɪm, saʊndɪŋ tʃɹaɪʌmfənt, ən laɪtnɪŋ kɹæʃt əkɹɔs ðə skaɪ ɪn ænsɝ.

"The Light, and Shinowa!" Ingtar's shout soared after him, sounding triumphant, and lightning crashed across the sky in answer.

ɹænd wɪpt ɹɛd wɪð ɪz ɹeɪnz, ðən leɪ əɡɛns ðə stæljənz nɛk əz ðə beɪ leɪɾ aʊɾ ɪn ə dɛd ɹʌn, meɪn ən teɪl stʃɹimɪŋ. hi wɪʃt i dɪd nɑt fil əz ɪf i wɝ ɹʌnɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ɪŋtʃɹz kɹaɪ, ɹʌnɪŋ fɹəm wʌɾ i wɑz səpoʊz tə du. ɪŋtʃɹ, ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd. aɪ doʊn kɛɹ. hi wɑz stɪl maɪ fɹɛnd. ðə beɪz ɡæləp kəd nɑt teɪk ɪm əweɪ fɹəm ɪz oʊn θɔts. dɛθ ɪz laɪɾɝ ðən ə fɛðɝ, duɾi hɛviɝ ðən ə maʊntən. soʊ mɛni duɾiz. ɛɡwin. ðə hɔɹn. feɪn. mæt ən ɪz dæɡɝ. waɪ kæn ðəɹ dʒʌs bi wʌn əɾ ə taɪm? aɪ hæv tə teɪk kɛɹ ʌv ɔl ə ðɛm. oʊ, laɪt, ɛɡwin!

Rand whipped Red with his reins, then lay against the stallion's neck as the bay laid out in a dead run, mane and tail streaming. He wished he did not feel as if he were running away from Ingtar's cry, running from what he was supposed to do. Ingtar, a Darkfriend. I don't care. He was still my friend. The bay's gallop could not take him away from his own thoughts. Death is lighter than a feather, duty heavier than a mountain. So many duties. Egwene. The Horn. Fain. Mat and his dagger. Why can't there just be one at a time? I have to take care of all of them. Oh, Light, Egwene!

hi ɹeɪn ɪn soʊ sʌɾənli ðət ɹɛd slɪd tə ə hɔlt, sɪɾɪŋ bæk ɑn ɪz hɔntʃɪz. ðeɪ wɝ ɪn ə skænti kɑps ə bɛɹ-bɹæntʃt tʃɹiz ətɑp wʌn ə ðə hɪlz oʊvɝlʊkɪŋ fɑlm. ði ʌðɝz ɡæləpt ʌp bɪhaɪn hɪm.

He reined in so suddenly that Red slid to a halt, sitting back on his haunches. They were in a scanty copse of bare-branched trees atop one of the hills overlooking Falme. The others galloped up behind him.

"wʌt dʒju min?" pɛɹɪn dɪmændəd. "wi kən hɛlp vɛɹɪn teɪk ðə hɔɹn wɛɹ ɪts səpoʊz tə ɡoʊ? wɛɹ ɑɹ jə ɡoʊɪŋ tə bi?"

"What do you mean?" Perrin demanded. "We can help Verin take the Horn where it's supposed to go? Where are you going to be?"

"meɪbi hiz ɡoʊɪŋ mæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi," mæt sɛd. "hi wʊdnt wɑnə steɪ wɪð əs ɪf i wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ mæd. wəd ju, ɹænd?"

"Maybe he's going mad already," Mat said. "He wouldn't want to stay with us if he was going mad. Would you, Rand?"

"ju θɹi teɪk ðə hɔɹn tə vɛɹɪn," ɹænd sɛd. ɛɡwin. soʊ mɛni θɹɛdz, ɪn soʊ mʌtʃ deɪnʒɝ. soʊ mɛni duɾiz. "ju də nɑt nid mi."

"You three take the Horn to Verin," Rand said. Egwene. So many threads, in so much danger. So many duties. "You do not need me."

mæt kɝɛs ðə dæɡɝz hɪlt. "ðæts ɔl vɛɹi wɛl, bʌt wʌɾ əbaʊt ju? bɝn mi, jə kæn bi ɡoʊɪŋ mæd jɛt. jə kænt!" hʊɹɪn ɡeɪpt ət ðɛm, nɑɾ ʌndɝstændɪŋ hæf ʌv ɪt.

Mat caressed the dagger's hilt. "That's all very well, but what about you? Burn me, you can't be going mad yet. You can't!" Hurin gaped at them, not understanding half of it.

"aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ bæk," ɹænd sɛd. "aɪ ʃəd nɛvɝ əv lɛft." sʌmhaʊ, ðət dɪd nɑt saʊn ɪɡzækli ɹaɪɾ ɪn ɪz oʊn ɪɹz; ɪt dɪd nɑt fil ɹaɪɾ ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz hɛd. "aɪ hæv tə ɡoʊ bæk. naʊ." ðət saʊndəd bɛɾɝ. "ɛɡwin ɪz stɪl ðɛɹ, ɹɪmɛmbɝ. wɪð wʌn ə ðoʊz kɑlɝz ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk."

"I'm going back," Rand said. "I should never have left." Somehow, that did not sound exactly right in his own ears; it did not feel right inside his head. "I have to go back. Now." That sounded better. "Egwene is still there, remember. With one of those collars around her neck."

"ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ?" mæt sɛd. "aɪ nɛvɝ sɔ hɝ. ɑə! ɪf jə seɪ ʃiz ðɛɹ, ðən ʃiz ðɛɹ. wɪl ɔl teɪk ðə hɔɹn tə vɛɹɪn, ən ðən wɪl ɔl ɡoʊ bæk fəɹ hɝ. jə doʊn θɪŋk aɪ wəd liv əɹ ðɛɹ, də ju?"

"Are you sure?" Mat said. "I never saw her. Aaaah! If you say she is there, then she's there. We'll all take the Horn to Verin, and then we will all go back for her. You don't think I would leave her there, do you?"

ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. θɹɛdz. duɾiz. hi fɛlt əz ɪf i wɝ əbaʊt tə ɪksploʊd laɪk ə faɪɝwɝk. laɪt, wʌts hæpənɪŋ tə mi? "mæt, vɛɹɪn mʌs teɪk jə ən ðət dæɡɝ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn, soʊ jə kən faɪnəli bi fɹi ʌv ɪt. jə doʊn əv ɛni taɪm tə weɪst."

Rand shook his head. Threads. Duties. He felt as if he were about to explode like a firework. Light, what's happening to me? "Mat, Verin must take you and that dagger to Tar Valon, so you can finally be free of it. You don't have any time to waste."

"seɪvɪŋ ɛɡwin ɪzənt weɪstɪŋ taɪm!" bʌt mæts hæn hæd taɪɾənd ɑn ðə dæɡɝ tɪl ɪt ʃʊk.

"Saving Egwene isn't wasting time!" But Mat's hand had tightened on the dagger till it shook.

"wi ɑɹən ɛni ʌv əs ɡoʊɪŋ bæk," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "nɑt jɛt. lʊk." hi pɔɪntəd bæk təwɔɹd fɑlm.

"We aren't any of us going back," Perrin said. "Not yet. Look." He pointed back toward Falme.

ðə wæɡən jɑɹdz ən hɔɹs lɑts wɝ tɝnɪŋ blæk wɪð sintʃæn soʊlʒɝz, θaʊzənz ə ðɛm ɹæŋk ɑn ɹæŋk, wɪð tʃɹups ə kævəlɹi ɹaɪɾɪŋ skeɪl bists əz wɛl əz ɑɹmɝd mɛn ɑn hɔɹsəz, kʌlɝfəl ɡɑnfənənz mɑɹkɪŋ ði ɔfəsɝz. ɡɹoʊm dɑɾəd ðə ɹæŋks, ən ʌðɝ stʃɹeɪnʒ kɹitʃɝz, ɔlmoʊs bʌt nɑt kwaɪt laɪk mɑnstʃɹəs bɝdz ən lɪzɝdz, ən ɡɹeɪt θɪŋz laɪk nʌθɪŋ i kəd dɪskɹaɪb, wɪð ɡɹeɪ, ɹɪŋkəl skɪn ən hjudʒ tʌsks. əɾ ɪntɝvəlz əlɔŋ ðə laɪnz stʊd sʌldəm ən deɪmeɪn baɪ ðə skɔɹ. ɹænd wʌndɝɾ ɪf ɛɡwin wɝ wʌn ə ðɛm. ɪn ðə taʊn bɪhaɪn ðə soʊlʒɝz, ə ɹuftɑp stɪl ɪksploʊɾəd naʊ ən əɡɛn, ən laɪtnɪŋ stɪl stʃɹik ðə skaɪ. tu flaɪɪŋ bists, wɪð lɛðɝi wɪŋz twɛnti spænz tɪp tə tɪp, sɔɹd haɪ oʊvɝhɛd, kipɪŋ wɛl əweɪ fɹəm wɛɹ ðə bɹaɪt boʊls dænst.

The wagon yards and horse lots were turning black with Seanchan soldiers, thousands of them rank on rank, with troops of cavalry riding scaled beasts as well as armored men on horses, colorful gonfanons marking the officers. Grolm dotted the ranks, and other strange creatures, almost but not quite like monstrous birds and lizards, and great things like nothing he could describe, with gray, wrinkled skin and huge tusks. At intervals along the lines stood sul'dam and damane by the score. Rand wondered if Egwene were one of them. In the town behind the soldiers, a rooftop still exploded now and again, and lightning still streaked the sky. Two flying beasts, with leathery wings twenty spans tip to tip, soared high overhead, keeping well away from where the bright bolts danced.

"ɔl ðət fəɹ ʌs?" mæt sɛɾ ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli. "hu də ðeɪ θɪŋk wi ɑɹ?"

"All that for us?" Mat said incredulously. "Who do they think we are?"

ən ænsɝ keɪm tə ɹænd, bʌɾ i ʃʌvd ɪɾ əweɪ bɪfɔɹ ɪt hæɾ ə tʃæns tə fɔɹm kəmplitli.

An answer came to Rand, but he shoved it away before it had a chance to form completely.

"wi ɑɹənt ɡoʊɪŋ ði ʌðɝ weɪ iðɝ, lɔɹd ɹænd," hʊɹɪn sɛd. "waɪtkloʊks. hʌnʒɹədz ə ðɛm."

"We aren't going the other way either, Lord Rand," Hurin said. "Whitecloaks. Hundreds of them."

ɹænd wild ɪz hɔɹs tə lʊk wɛɹ ðə snɪfɝ wɑz pɔɪntɪŋ. ə lɔŋ, waɪt-kloʊk laɪn ɹɪpəl sloʊli təwɔɹɾ əm əkɹɔs ðə hɪlz.

Rand wheeled his horse to look where the sniffer was pointing. A long, white-cloaked line rippled slowly toward them across the hills.

"lɔɹd ɹænd," hʊɹɪn mʌɾɝd, "ɪf ðət lɑt leɪz ən aɪ ɑn ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ, wɪl nɛvɝ ɡɛɾ ɪt kloʊs tə ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. wɪl nɛvɝ ɡɛt kloʊs tə ɪɾ əɡɛn aʊɝsɛlvz."

"Lord Rand," Hurin muttered, "if that lot lays an eye on the Horn of Valere, we'll never get it close to an Aes Sedai. We'll never get close to it again ourselves."

"meɪbi ðæts waɪ ðə sintʃæn ɑɹ ɡæðɝɪŋ," mæt sɛd hoʊpfəli. "bɪkɔz ə ðə waɪtkloʊks. meɪbi ɪt dʌzn əv ɛniθɪŋ tə də wɪð əs əɾ ɔl."

"Maybe that's why the Seanchan are gathering," Mat said hopefully. "Because of the Whitecloaks. Maybe it doesn't have anything to do with us at all."

"wɛðɝ ɪt dʌz əɹ nɑt," pɛɹɪn sɛd dʒɹaɪli, "ðɛɹ ɪz gɑnə bi ə bæɾəl hɪɹ ɪn ə fju mɪnəts."

"Whether it does or not," Perrin said dryly, "there is going to be a battle here in a few minutes."

"iðɝ saɪd kəd kɪl ʌs," hʊɹɪn sɛd, "ivən ɪf ðeɪ nɛvɝ si ðə hɔɹn. ɪf ðeɪ du. . . ."

"Either side could kill us," Hurin said, "even if they never see the Horn. If they do. . . ."

ɹænd kəd nɑt mænədʒ tə θɪŋk əbaʊt ðə waɪtkloʊks, əɹ ðə sintʃæn. aɪ hæv tə ɡoʊ bæk. hæv tə. hi wɑz stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ, hi ɹilaɪzd. ðeɪ ɔl wɝ. ðə kɝld, ɡoʊldən hɔɹn hʌŋ ət mæts pɑməl, ðə foʊkəs ʌv ɛvɹi aɪ.

Rand could not manage to think about the Whitecloaks, or the Seanchan. I have to go back. Have to. He was staring at the Horn of Valere, he realized. They all were. The curled, golden Horn hung at Mat's pommel, the focus of every eye.

"ɪɾ əz tə bi ðəɹ ət ðə læs bæɾəl," mæt sɛd, lɪkɪŋ ɪz lɪps. "nʌθɪŋ sɛz ɪt kæn bi juz bɪfɔɹ ðɛn." hi pʊl ðə hɔɹn fɹi ʌv ɪts læʃɪŋz ən lʊkt əɾ əm æŋkʃəsli. "nʌθɪŋ sɛz ɪt kænt."

"It has to be there at the Last Battle," Mat said, licking his lips. "Nothing says it can't be used before then." He pulled the Horn free of its lashings and looked at them anxiously. "Nothing says it can't."

noʊ wʌn ɛls sɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ. ɹænd dɪd nɑt θɪŋk i kəd spik; hɪz oʊn θɔts wɝ tu ɝdʒən tə əlaʊ ɹum fəɹ spitʃ. hæv tə ɡoʊ bæk. hæv tə ɡoʊ bæk. ðə lɔŋɡɝ i lʊkt ət ðə hɔɹn, ðə mɔɹ ɝdʒən ɪz θɔts bɪkeɪm. hæv tə. hæv tə.

No one else said anything. Rand did not think he could speak; his own thoughts were too urgent to allow room for speech. Have to go back. Have to go back. The longer he looked at the Horn, the more urgent his thoughts became. Have to. Have to.

mæts hænd ʃʊk əz i ɹeɪz ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ tə hɪz lɪps.

Mat's hand shook as he raised the Horn of Valere to his lips.

ɪt wɑz ə klɪɹ noʊt, ɡoʊldən əz ðə hɔɹn wɑz ɡoʊldən. ðə tʃɹiz ɝaʊn əm sim tə ɹɛzəneɪt wɪð ɪt, ən ðə ɡɹaʊn ʌndɝ ðɛɹ fit, ðə skaɪ oʊvɝhɛd. ðət wʌn lɔŋ saʊn ɛnkʌmpəst ɛvɹiθɪŋ.

It was a clear note, golden as the Horn was golden. The trees around them seemed to resonate with it, and the ground under their feet, the sky overhead. That one long sound encompassed everything.

aʊɾ ə noʊwɛɹ, ə fɑɡ bɪɡæn tə ɹaɪz. fɝs θɪn wɪsps hæŋɪŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ, ðən θɪkɝ bɪloʊz, ən θɪkɝ, əntɪl ɪt blæŋkəɾɪd ðə læn laɪk klaʊdz.

Out of nowhere, a fog began to rise. First thin wisps hanging in the air, then thicker billows, and thicker, until it blanketed the land like clouds.

dʒɛəfɹæm bɔɹnhəl stɪfən ɪn ɪz sæɾəl əz ə saʊn fɪl ði ɛɹ, soʊ swiɾ i wɑntəd tə læf, soʊ mɔɹnfəl i wɑntəd tə kɹaɪ. ɪt sim tə kʌm fɹəm ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən ət wʌns. ə mɪs bɪɡæn tə ɹaɪz, ɡɹoʊɪŋ ivən əz i wɑtʃt.

Geofram Bornhald stiffened in his saddle as a sound filled the air, so sweet he wanted to laugh, so mournful he wanted to cry. It seemed to come from every direction at once. A mist began to rise, growing even as he watched.

ðə sintʃæn. ðeɪ ɑɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ. ðeɪ noʊ wəɹ hɪɹ.

The Seanchan. They are trying something. They know we are here.

ɪt wɑz tu sun, ðə taʊn tu fɑɹ, bʌɾ i dʒɹu hɪz sɔɹd - ə klæɾɝ ə skæbɝdz ɹæn daʊn ðə ɹæŋk ə hɪz hæf lidʒən - ən kɔld, "ðə lidʒən wɪl ədvæns əɾ ə tʃɹɑt."

It was too soon, the town too far, but he drew his sword - a clatter of scabbards ran down the rank of his half legion - and called, "The legion will advance at a trot."

ðə fɑɡ kʌvɝɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ, naʊ, bʌɾ i nu fɑlm wɑz stɪl ðɛɹ, əhɛd. ðə peɪs ə ðə hɔɹsəz pɪkt ʌp; hi kəd nɑt si ðɛm, bʌɾ i kəd hɪɹ.

The fog covered everything, now, but he knew Falme was still there, ahead. The pace of the horses picked up; he could not see them, but he could hear.

əbɹʌpli ðə ɡɹaʊn əhɛd flu ʌp wɪð ə ɹɔɹ, ʃaʊɝɪŋ ɪm wɪð dɝɾ ən pɛbəlz. fɹəm ðə waɪt blaɪndnəs tə hɪz ɹaɪɾ i hɝɾ ənʌðɝ ɹɔɹ, ən mɛn ən hɔɹsəz skɹimd, ðən fɹəm ɪz lɛft, ən əɡɛn. əɡɛn. θʌndɝ ən skɹimz, hɪɾən baɪ ðə fɑɡ.

Abruptly the ground ahead flew up with a roar, showering him with dirt and pebbles. From the white blindness to his right he heard another roar, and men and horses screamed, then from his left, and again. Again. Thunder and screams, hidden by the fog.

"ðə lidʒən wɪl tʃɑɹdʒ!" hɪz hɔɹs lɛp fɔɹwɝɾ əz i dʌɡ ɪn ɪz hilz, ən i hɝd ðə ɹɔɹ əz ðə lidʒən, əz mʌtʃ ʌv ɪɾ əz stɪl lɪvd, fɑloʊd.

"The legion will charge!" His horse leaped forward as he dug in his heels, and he heard the roar as the legion, as much of it as still lived, followed.

θʌndɝ ən skɹimz, ɹæpt ɪn waɪtnəs.

Thunder and screams, wrapped in whiteness.

hɪz læs θɔt wɑz ɹəɡɹɛt. baɪɑɝ wəd nɑt bi eɪbəl tə tɛl ɪz sʌn deɪn haʊ hi hæd daɪd.

His last thought was regret. Byar would not be able to tell his son Dain how he had died.

ɹænd kəd nɑt si ðə tʃɹiz ɝaʊn əm ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. mæt hæd loʊɝd ðə hɔɹn, aɪz waɪd wɪð ɑ, bʌt ðə saʊn ʌv ɪt stɪl ɹæŋ ɪn ɹændz ɪɹz. ðə fɑɡ hɪɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪn ɹoʊlɪŋ weɪvz əz waɪɾ əz ðə faɪnəs blitʃt wʊl, jɛt ɹænd kəd si. hi kəd si, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz mæd. fɑlm floʊɾəd sʌmwɛɹ bɪniθ hɪm, ɪts lændwɝd bɔɹɾɝ blæk wɪð ðə sintʃæn ɹæŋks, laɪtnɪŋ ɹɪpɪŋ ɪts stʃɹits. fɑlm hʌŋ oʊvɝ ɪz hɛd. ðəɹ waɪtkloʊks tʃɑɹdʒd ən daɪɾ əz ði ɝθ oʊpən ɪn faɪɝ bɪniθ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz' hʊvz. ðəɹ mɛn ɹæn əbaʊt ðə dɛks ə tɔl, skwɛɹ ʃɪps ɪn ðə hɑɹbɝ, ən ɑn wʌn ʃɪp, ə fəmɪljɝ ʃɪp, fɪɹfəl mɛn weɪɾəd. hi kəɾ ivən ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə feɪs ə ðə kæptən. beɪl doʊmən. hi klʌtʃt ɪz hɛd wɪð boʊθ hænz. ðə tʃɹiz wɝ hɪɾən, bʌɾ i kəd stɪl si itʃ ə ði ʌðɝz klɪɹli. hʊɹɪn æŋkʃəs. mæt mʌɾɝɪŋ, fɪɹfəl. pɛɹɪn lʊkɪŋ əz ɪf i nu ðɪs wɑz mɛn tə bi. ðə fɑɡ ɹɔɪld ʌp ɔl ɝaʊn ðɛm.

Rand could not see the trees around them any longer. Mat had lowered the Horn, eyes wide with awe, but the sound of it still rang in Rand's ears. The fog hid everything in rolling waves as white as the finest bleached wool, yet Rand could see. He could see, but it was mad. Falme floated somewhere beneath him, its landward border black with the Seanchan ranks, lightning ripping its streets. Falme hung over his head. There Whitecloaks charged and died as the earth opened in fire beneath their horses' hooves. There men ran about the decks of tall, square ships in the harbor, and on one ship, a familiar ship, fearful men waited. He could even recognize the face of the captain. Bayle Domon. He clutched his head with both hands. The trees were hidden, but he could still see each of the others clearly. Hurin anxious. Mat muttering, fearful. Perrin looking as if he knew this was meant to be. The fog roiled up all around them.

hʊɹɪn ɡæspt. "lɔɹd ɹænd!" ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid fəɹ ɪm tə pɔɪnt.

Hurin gasped. "Lord Rand!" There was no need for him to point.

daʊn ðə bɪloʊɪŋ fɑɡ, əz ɪf ɪt wɝ ðə saɪɾ ʌv ə maʊntən, ɹoʊd ʃeɪps ɑn hɔɹsəz. ət fɝs ðə dɛns mɪsts hɪd mɔɹ ðən ðæt, bʌt sloʊli ðeɪ keɪm kloʊsɝ, ən ɪt wɑz ɹændz tɝn tə ɡæsp. hi nu ðɛm. mɛn, nɑɾ ɔl ɪn ɑɹmɝ, ən wɪmən. ðɛɹ kloʊðz ən ðɛɹ wɛpənz keɪm fɹəm ɛvɹi eɪdʒ, bʌɾ i nu ðɛm ɔl.

Down the billowing fog, as if it were the side of a mountain, rode shapes on horses. At first the dense mists hid more than that, but slowly they came closer, and it was Rand's turn to gasp. He knew them. Men, not all in armor, and women. Their clothes and their weapons came from every Age, but he knew them all.

ɹəɡoʊʃ iɡəl-aɪ, ə fɑðɝli lʊkɪŋ mæn wɪð waɪt hɛɹ ən aɪz soʊ ʃɑɹp əz tə meɪk ɪz neɪm mɪɹli ə hɪnt. ɡeɪɾəl keɪn, ə swɔɹði mæn wɪð ðə hɪls ə hɪz tu sɔɹdz stɪkɪŋ əbʌv ɪz bɹɔd ʃoʊldɝz. ɡoʊldən-hɛɹd bɝdʒɪt, wɪð əɹ ɡlimɪŋ sɪlvɝ baʊ ən kwɪvɝ bɹɪsəlɪŋ wɪð sɪlvɝ æɹoʊz. mɔɹ. hi nu ðɛɹ feɪsəz, nu ðɛɹ neɪmz. bʌɾ i hɝɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd neɪmz wən i lʊkt əɾ itʃ feɪs, səm soʊ dɪfɹən i dɪd nɑt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz əm əz neɪmz əɾ ɔl, ðoʊ hi nu ðeɪ wɝ. maɪkəl ɪnstɛɾ ə mɪkəl. pætʃɹɪk ɪnstɛɾ ə peɪədʒɹɪɡ. ɔskɝ ɪnstɛɾ ʌv oʊɾɝɪn.

Rogosh Eagle-eye, a fatherly looking man with white hair and eyes so sharp as to make his name merely a hint. Gaidal Cain, a swarthy man with the hilts of his two swords sticking above his broad shoulders. Golden-haired Birgitte, with her gleaming silver bow and quiver bristling with silver arrows. More. He knew their faces, knew their names. But he heard a hundred names when he looked at each face, some so different he did not recognize them as names at all, though he knew they were. Michael instead of Mikel. Patrick instead of Paedrig. Oscar instead of Otarin.

hi nu ðə mæn u ɹoʊɾ ət ðɛɹ hɛd, tu. tɔl ən hʊk-noʊzd, wɪð dɑɹk, dip-sɛɾ aɪz, hɪz ɡɹeɪt sɔɹd dʒʌstəs əɾ ɪz saɪd. ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ.

He knew the man who rode at their head, too. Tall and hook-nosed, with dark, deep-set eyes, his great sword Justice at his side. Artur Hawkwing.

mæt ɡeɪpt əɾ əm əz ðeɪ ɹeɪn ɪn bɪfɔɹ ɪm ən ði ʌðɝz. "ɪz ðɪs . . . ? ɪz ðɪs ɔl ə ju?" ðeɪ wɝ lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən ə hʌnʒɹəd, ɹænd sɔ, ən ɹilaɪz ðət sʌmhaʊ hi hæd noʊn ðət ðeɪ wəd bi. hʊɹɪnz maʊθ hʌŋ oʊpən; hɪz aɪz bʌlʒd ɔlmoʊst aʊɾ ə hɪz hɛd.

Mat gaped at them as they reined in before him and the others. "Is this . . . ? Is this all of you?" They were little more than a hundred, Rand saw, and realized that somehow he had known that they would be. Hurin's mouth hung open; his eyes bulged almost out of his head.

"ɪt teɪks mɔɹ ðən bɹeɪvɝi tə baɪn ə mæn tə ðə hɔɹn." ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz vɔɪs wɑz dip ən kæɹiɪŋ, ə vɔɪs juz tə ɡɪvɪŋ kəmænz.

"It takes more than bravery to bind a man to the Horn." Artur Hawkwing's voice was deep and carrying, a voice used to giving commands.

"ɔɹ ə wʊmən," bɝdʒɪt sɛd ʃɑɹpli.

"Or a woman," Birgitte said sharply.

"ɔɹ ə wʊmən," hɔkwɪŋ əɡɹid. "oʊnli ə fju ɑɹ baʊn tə ðə wil, spʌn aʊɾ əɡɛn ən əɡɛn tə wɝk ðə wɪl ə ðə wil ɪn ðə pæɾɝn ə ði eɪdʒəz. jə kəd tɛl hɪm, luz θɝɪn, kəd jə bʌt ɹɪmɛmbɝ wən jə wɔɹ flɛʃ." hi wɑz lʊkɪŋ ət ɹænd.

"Or a woman," Hawkwing agreed. "Only a few are bound to the Wheel, spun out again and again to work the will of the Wheel in the Pattern of the Ages. You could tell him, Lews Therin, could you but remember when you wore flesh." He was looking at Rand.

ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, bʌɾ i wəd nɑt weɪs taɪm wɪð dɪnaɪəlz. "ɪnveɪɾɝz əv kʌm, mɛn u kɔl ðɛmsɛlvz sintʃæn, hu juz tʃeɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn bæɾəl. ðeɪ mʌs bi dʒɹɪvən bæk ɪndə ðə si. ən - ən ðəɹ ɪz ə ɡɝl. ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ. ə nɑvəs fɹəm ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ðə sintʃæn əv əɹ pɹɪznɝ. jə mʌs hɛlp mi fɹi hɝ."

Rand shook his head, but he would not waste time with denials. "Invaders have come, men who call themselves Seanchan, who use chained Aes Sedai in battle. They must be driven back into the sea. And - and there is a girl. Egwene al'Vere. A novice from the White Tower. The Seanchan have her prisoner. You must help me free her."

tə hɪz sɝpɹaɪz, sɛvɹəl ə ðə smɔl hoʊs bɪhaɪn ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ tʃʌkəld, ən bɝdʒɪt, tɛstɪŋ əɹ bɑstʃɹɪŋ, læft. "ju ɔlweɪz tʃuz wɪmən u kɑz jə tʃɹʌbəl, luz θɝɪn." ɪt hæɾ ə fɑn saʊnd, əz bɪtwin oʊl fɹɛnz.

To his surprise, several of the small host behind Artur Hawkwing chuckled, and Birgitte, testing her bowstring, laughed. "You always choose women who cause you trouble, Lews Therin." It had a fond sound, as between old friends.

"maɪ neɪm ɪz ɹænd ælθɹ," hi snæpt. "ju hæv tə hɝi. ðəɹ ɪzən mʌtʃ taɪm."

"My name is Rand al'Thor," he snapped. "You have to hurry. There isn't much time."

"taɪm?" bɝdʒɪt sɛd, smaɪlɪŋ. "wi hæv ɔl ə taɪm." ɡeɪɾəl keɪn dʒɹɑpt ɪz ɹeɪnz ænd, ɡaɪɾɪŋ ɪz hɔɹs wɪð ɪz niz, dʒɹu ə sɔɹɾ ɪn iðɝ hænd. ɔl əlɔŋ ðə smɔl bæn ə hɪɹoʊz ðəɹ wɑz ən ənʃiðɪŋ ə sɔɹdz, ən ənlɪmbɝɪŋ ə baʊz, ə hɛftɪŋ ə spɪɹz ən æksiz.

"Time?" Birgitte said, smiling. "We have all of time." Gaidal Cain dropped his reins and, guiding his horse with his knees, drew a sword in either hand. All along the small band of heroes there was an unsheathing of swords, an unlimbering of bows, a hefting of spears and axes.

dʒʌstəs ʃoʊn laɪk ə mɪɹɝ ɪn ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz ɡɔntələɾəd fɪst. "aɪ hæv fɔt baɪ jəɹ saɪd taɪmz bɪɑnd nʌmbɝ, luz θɝɪn, ən feɪs jə əz mɛni mɔɹ. ðə wil spɪnz əs aʊt fəɹ ɪts pɝpəsəz, nɑɾ aʊɝz, tə sɝv ðə pæɾɝn. aɪ noʊ ju, ɪf jə də nɑt noʊ jɝsɛlf. wɪl dʒɹaɪv ðiz ɪnveɪɾɝz aʊt fəɹ ju." hɪz wɔɹhɔɹs pɹænst, ən i lʊkt ɝaʊnd, fɹaʊnɪŋ. "sʌmθɪŋ ɪz ɹɔŋ hɪɹ. sʌmθɪŋ hoʊlz mi." sʌɾənli hi tɝn ɪz ʃɑɹp-aɪd ɡeɪz ɑn ɹænd. "ju ɑɹ hɪɹ. hæv jə ðə bænɝ?" ə mɝmɝ ɹæn θɹu ðoʊz bɪhaɪn hɪm.

Justice shone like a mirror in Artur Hawkwing's gauntleted fist. "I have fought by your side times beyond number, Lews Therin, and faced you as many more. The Wheel spins us out for its purposes, not ours, to serve the Pattern. I know you, if you do not know yourself. We will drive these invaders out for you." His warhorse pranced, and he looked around, frowning. "Something is wrong here. Something holds me." Suddenly he turned his sharp-eyed gaze on Rand. "You are here. Have you the banner?" A murmur ran through those behind him.

"jɛs." ɹænd tɔɹ oʊpən ðə stʃɹæps ə hɪz sæɾəlbæɡz ən pʊld aʊt ðə dʒɹæɡənz bænɝ. ɪt fɪld ɪz hænz ən hʌŋ ɔlmoʊs tə hɪz stæljənz niz. ðə mɝmɝ əmʌŋ ðə hɪɹoʊz ɹoʊz.

"Yes." Rand tore open the straps of his saddlebags and pulled out the Dragon's banner. It filled his hands and hung almost to his stallion's knees. The murmur among the heroes rose.

"ðə pæɾɝn wivz ɪtsɛlf ɝaʊn əɹ nɛks laɪk hɔltɝz," ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ sɛd. "ju ɑɹ hɪɹ. ðə bænɝ ɪz hɪɹ. ðə wiv ə ðɪs moʊmən ɪz sɛt. wɪv kʌm tə ðə hɔɹn, bʌt wi mʌs fɑloʊ ðə bænɝ. ən ðə dʒɹæɡən." hʊɹɪn meɪɾ ə feɪn saʊn əz ɪf ɪz θɹoʊt hæd sizd.

"The Pattern weaves itself around our necks like halters," Artur Hawkwing said. "You are here. The banner is here. The weave of this moment is set. We have come to the Horn, but we must follow the banner. And the Dragon." Hurin made a faint sound as if his throat had seized.

"bɝn mi," mæt bɹiðd. "ɪts tʃɹu. bɝn mi!"

"Burn me," Mat breathed. "It's true. Burn me!"

pɛɹɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd oʊnli ən ɪnstən bɪfɔɹ swɪŋɪŋ daʊn ɔf ɪz hɔɹs ən stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪndə ðə mɪst. ðəɹ keɪm ə tʃɑpɪŋ saʊnd, ən wən i ɹɪtɝnd, hi kæɹiɾ ə stʃɹeɪt lɛŋθ ə sæpəlɪŋ ʃɔɹn ʌv ɪts bɹæntʃəz. "ɡɪv ɪt tə mi, ɹænd," hi sɛd ɡɹeɪvli. "ɪf ðeɪ niɾ ɪt. . . . ɡɪv ɪt tə mi."

Perrin hesitated only an instant before swinging down off his horse and striding into the mist. There came a chopping sound, and when he returned, he carried a straight length of sapling shorn of its branches. "Give it to me, Rand," he said gravely. "If they need it. . . . Give it to me."

heɪstəli, ɹænd hɛlpt ɪm taɪ ðə bænɝ tə ðə poʊl. wən pɛɹɪn ɹimaʊntɪd, poʊl ɪn hænd, ə kɝən ʌv ɛɹ sim tə ɹɪpəl ðə peɪl lɛŋθ ə ðə bænɝ, soʊ ðə sɝpəntaɪn dʒɹæɡən əpɪɹd tə muv, əlaɪv. ðə wɪn dɪd nɑt tʌtʃ ðə hɛvi fɑɡ, oʊnli ðə bænɝ.

Hastily, Rand helped him tie the banner to the pole. When Perrin remounted, pole in hand, a current of air seemed to ripple the pale length of the banner, so the serpentine Dragon appeared to move, alive. The wind did not touch the heavy fog, only the banner.

"ju steɪ hɪɹ," ɹænd toʊl hʊɹɪn. "wɛn ɪts oʊvɝ. . . . jəl bi seɪf, hɪɹ."

"You stay here," Rand told Hurin. "When it's over. . . . You will be safe, here."

hʊɹɪn dʒɹu hɪz ʃɔɹt sɔɹd, hoʊldɪŋ ɪɾ əz ɪf ɪt maɪɾ æktʃəli  bi ʌv səm jus fɹəm hɔɹsbæk. "bɛɡɪŋ jəɹ pɑɹɾən, lɔɹd ɹænd, bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk nɑt. aɪ doʊn ʌndɝstæn ðə tɛnθ pɑɹɾ ʌv wʌɾ aɪv hɝd . . . əɹ wʌɾ aɪm siɪŋ" - hɪz vɔɪs dʒɹɑp tə ə mʌɾɝ bɪfɔɹ pɪkɪŋ ʌp əɡɛn - "bʌɾ aɪv kʌm ðɪs fɑɹ, ən aɪ θɪŋk əl ɡoʊ ðə ɹɛst ə ðə weɪ."

Hurin drew his short sword, holding it as if it might actually be of some use from horseback. "Begging your pardon, Lord Rand, but I think not. I don't understand the tenth part of what I've heard . . . or what I'm seeing" - his voice dropped to a mutter before picking up again - "but I've come this far, and I think I'll go the rest of the way."

ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ klæp ðə snɪfɝ ɑn ðə ʃoʊldɝ. "səmtaɪmz ðə wil ædz tə əɹ nʌmbɝ, fɹɛnd. pɝhæps jəl faɪn jɝsɛlf əmʌŋ ʌs, wʌn deɪ." hʊɹɪn sæɾ ʌp əz ɪf i hæd bɪn ɔfɝɾ ə kɹaʊn. hɔkwɪŋ baʊd fɔɹməli fɹəm ɪz sæɾəl tə ɹænd. "wɪð jəɹ pɝmɪʃən . . . lɔɹd ɹænd. tʃɹʌmpəɾɝ, wɪl jə ɡɪv əs mjuzɪk ɑn ðə hɔɹn? fɪɾɪŋ ðət ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ ʃəd sɪŋ əs ɪndə bæɾəl. bænɝmən, wɪl jə ədvæns?"

Artur Hawkwing clapped the sniffer on the shoulder. "Sometimes the Wheel adds to our number, friend. Perhaps you will find yourself among us, one day." Hurin sat up as if he had been offered a crown. Hawkwing bowed formally from his saddle to Rand. "With your permission . . . Lord Rand. Trumpeter, will you give us music on the Horn? Fitting that the Horn of Valere should sing us into battle. Bannerman, will you advance?"

mæt saʊndəd ðə hɔɹn əɡɛn, lɔŋ ən haɪ - ðə mɪsts ɹæŋ wɪð ɪt - ən pɛɹɪn hild ɪz hɔɹs fɔɹwɝd. ɹænd dʒɹu ðə hɛɹən-mɑɹk bleɪɾ ən ɹoʊd bɪtwin ðɛm.

Mat sounded the Horn again, long and high - the mists rang with it - and Perrin heeled his horse forward. Rand drew the heron-mark blade and rode between them.

hi kəd si nʌθɪŋ bʌt θɪk bɪloʊz ʌv waɪt, bʌt sʌmhaʊ hi kəd stɪl si wʌɾ i hæd bɪfɔɹ, tu. fɑlm, wɛɹ sʌmwʌn juz ðə paʊɝ ɪn ðə stʃɹits, ən ðə hɑɹbɝ, ən ðə sintʃæn hoʊst, ən ðə daɪɪŋ waɪtkloʊks, ɔl ʌv ɪt bɪniθ hɪm, ɔl ə hɪm hæŋɪŋ əbʌv, ɔl ʌv ɪt dʒʌst əz ɪt hæd bɪn. ɪt simd əz ɪf noʊ taɪm əɾ ɔl hæd pæst sɪns ðə hɔɹn wɑz fɝs bloʊn, əz ðoʊ taɪm hæd pɔzd waɪl ðə hɪɹoʊz ænsɝd ðə kɔl ən naʊ ɹɪzum kaʊntɪŋ.

He could see nothing but thick billows of white, but somehow he could still see what he had before, too. Falme, where someone used the Power in the streets, and the harbor, and the Seanchan host, and the dying Whitecloaks, all of it beneath him, all of him hanging above, all of it just as it had been. It seemed as if no time at all had passed since the Horn was first blown, as though time had paused while the heroes answered the call and now resumed counting.

ðə waɪl kɹaɪz mæt ɹʌŋ fɹəm ðə hɔɹn ɛkoʊɾ ɪn ðə fɑɡ, ən ðə dʒɹʌmɪŋ ə hʊvz əz ðə hɔɹsəz pɪkt ʌp spid. ɹænd tʃɑɹdʒd ɪndə ðə mɪsts, wʌndɝɪŋ ɪf i nu wɛɹ i wɑz hɛɾəd. ðə klaʊdz θɪkənd, haɪɾɪŋ ðə fɑɹ ɛnz ə ðə ɹæŋk ə hɪɹoʊz ɡæləpɪŋ tə iðɝ saɪɾ ə hɪm, əbskjʊɹɪŋ mɔɹ ən mɔɹ, tɪl i kəd si oʊnli mæt ən pɛɹɪn ən hʊɹɪn klɪɹli. hʊɹɪn kɹaʊtʃt loʊ ɪn ɪz sæɾəl, waɪd-aɪd, ɝdʒɪŋ ɪz hɔɹs ɑn. mæt saʊndɪŋ ðə hɔɹn, ən læfɪŋ bɪtwin. pɛɹɪn, hɪz jɛloʊ aɪz ɡloʊɪŋ, ðə dʒɹæɡənz bænɝ stʃɹimɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɪm. ðən ðeɪ wɝ ɡɔn, tu, ən ɹænd ɹoʊɾ ɑn əloʊn, əz ɪt simd.

The wild cries Mat wrung from the Horn echoed in the fog, and the drumming of hooves as the horses picked up speed. Rand charged into the mists, wondering if he knew where he was headed. The clouds thickened, hiding the far ends of the rank of heroes galloping to either side of him, obscuring more and more, till he could see only Mat and Perrin and Hurin clearly. Hurin crouched low in his saddle, wide-eyed, urging his horse on. Mat sounding the Horn, and laughing between. Perrin, his yellow eyes glowing, the Dragon's banner streaming behind him. Then they were gone, too, and Rand rode on alone, as it seemed.

ɪn ə weɪ, hi kəd stɪl si ðɛm, bʌt naʊ ɪt wɑz ðə weɪ hi kəd si fɑlm, ən ðə sintʃæn. hi kəd nɑt tɛl wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ, əɹ wɛɹ i wɑz. hi taɪɾənd ɪz ɡɹɪp ɑn ɪz sɔɹd, pɪɹɾ ɪndə ðə mɪsts əhɛd. hi tʃɑɹdʒd əloʊn θɹu ðə fɑɡ, ən sʌmhaʊ hi nu ðət wɑz haʊ ɪt wɑz mɛn tə bi.

In a way, he could still see them, but now it was the way he could see Falme, and the Seanchan. He could not tell where they were, or where he was. He tightened his grip on his sword, peered into the mists ahead. He charged alone through the fog, and somehow he knew that was how it was meant to be.

sʌɾənli bælzəmən wɑz bɪfɔɹ ɪm ɪn ðə mɪsts, θɹoʊɪŋ ɪz ɑɹmz waɪd.

Suddenly Ba'alzamon was before him in the mists, throwing his arms wide.

ɹɛd ɹɪɹd waɪldli, hɝlɪŋ ɹænd fɹəm ɪz sæɾəl. ɹænd klʌŋ tə hɪz sɔɹd dɛspɝətli əz i sɔɹd. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə hɑɹd lændɪŋ. ɪn fækt, hi θɔt wɪð ə sɛns ʌv wʌndɝ ðəɾ ɪt wɑz vɛɹi mʌtʃ laɪk lændɪŋ ɑn . . . nʌθɪŋ əɾ ɔl. wʌn ɪnstən i wɑz seɪlɪŋ θɹu ðə mɪsts, ən ðə nɛkst i wɑz nɑt.

Red reared wildly, hurling Rand from his saddle. Rand clung to his sword desperately as he soared. It was not a hard landing. In fact, he thought with a sense of wonder that it was very much like landing on . . . nothing at all. One instant he was sailing through the mists, and the next he was not.

wən i klaɪm tə hɪz fit, hɪz hɔɹs wɑz ɡɔn, bʌt bælzəmən wɑz stɪl ðɛɹ, stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ təwɔɹɾ ɪm wɪð ə lɔŋ, blæk-tʃɑɹd stæf ɪn ɪz hænz. ðeɪ wɝ əloʊn, oʊnli ðeɪ ən ðə ɹoʊlɪŋ fɑɡ. bɪhaɪn bælzəmən wɑz ʃædoʊ. ðə mɪst wɑz nɑt dɑɹk bɪhaɪn hɪm; ðɪs blæknəs ɪkskluɾəd ðə waɪt fɑɡ.

When he climbed to his feet, his horse was gone, but Ba'alzamon was still there, striding toward him with a long, black-charred staff in his hands. They were alone, only they and the rolling fog. Behind Ba'alzamon was shadow. The mist was not dark behind him; this blackness excluded the white fog.

ɹænd wɑz əwɛɹ ə ði ʌðɝ θɪŋz, tu. ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ ən ði ʌðɝ hɪɹoʊz miɾɪŋ ðə sintʃæn ɪn dɛns fɑɡ. pɛɹɪn, wɪð ðə bænɝ, swɪŋɪŋ ɪz æks mɔɹ tə fɛn ɔf ðoʊz u tʃɹaɪd tə ɹitʃ ɪm ðən hɑɹm ðɛm. mæt, stɪl bloʊɪŋ waɪl noʊts ɑn ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ. hʊɹɪn daʊn fɹəm ɪz sæɾəl, faɪɾɪŋ wɪð ʃɔɹt sɔɹɾ ən sɔɹd-bɹeɪkɝ ɪn ðə weɪ hi nu. ɪt simd əz ɪf ðə sintʃæn nʌmbɝz wəɾ oʊvɝwɛlm əm ɪn wʌn ɹʌʃ, jɛɾ ɪt wɑz ðə dɑɹk-ɑɹmɝd sintʃæn u fɛl bæk.

Rand was aware of the other things, too. Artur Hawkwing and the other heroes meeting the Seanchan in dense fog. Perrin, with the banner, swinging his axe more to fend off those who tried to reach him than harm them. Mat, still blowing wild notes on the Horn of Valere. Hurin down from his saddle, fighting with short sword and sword-breaker in the way he knew. It seemed as if the Seanchan numbers would overwhelm them in one rush, yet it was the dark-armored Seanchan who fell back.

ɹænd wɛn fɔɹwɝd tə mit bælzəmən. ɹɪlʌktənli, hi əsum ðə vɔɪd, ɹitʃt fəɹ ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs, wɑz fɪld wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ʌðɝ weɪ. pɝhæps i hæd noʊ tʃæns əɡɛns ðə dɑɹk wʌn, bʌt wʌtɛvɝ tʃæns i dɪɾ əv leɪ ɪn ðə paʊɝ. ɪt soʊkt ɪndə hɪz lɪmz, sim tə sʌfjus ɛvɹiθɪŋ əbaʊt hɪm, hɪz kloʊðz, hɪz sɔɹd. hi fɛlt əz ɪf i ʃəd bi ɡloʊɪŋ laɪk ðə sʌn. ɪt θɹɪl hɪm; ɪt meɪɾ ɪm wɑnə vɑmət.

Rand went forward to meet Ba'alzamon. Reluctantly, he assumed the void, reached for the True Source, was filled with the One Power. There was no other way. Perhaps he had no chance against the Dark One, but whatever chance he did have lay in the Power. It soaked into his limbs, seemed to suffuse everything about him, his clothes, his sword. He felt as if he should be glowing like the sun. It thrilled him; it made him want to vomit.

"ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə maɪ weɪ," hi ɡɹeɪɾɪd. "aɪ æm nɑt hɪɹ fəɹ ju!"

"Get out of my way," he grated. "I am not here for you!"

"ðə ɡɝl?" bælzəmən læft. hɪz maʊθ tɝn tə fleɪm. hɪz bɝnz wɝ ɔl bʌt hild, livɪŋ oʊnli ə fju pɪŋk skɑɹz ðət wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi feɪɾɪŋ. hi lʊk laɪk ə hænsəm mæn ə mɪɾəl jɪɹz. ɪksɛp fəɹ ɪz maʊθ, ən ɪz aɪz. "wɪtʃ wʌn, luz θɝɪn? jəl nɑɾ əv ɛniwʌn tə hɛlp jə ðɪs taɪm. jə ɑɹ maɪn, əɹ jə ɑɹ dɛd. ɪn wɪtʃ keɪs, jə ɑɹ maɪn ɛniweɪ."

"The girl?" Ba'alzamon laughed. His mouth turned to flame. His burns were all but healed, leaving only a few pink scars that were already fading. He looked like a handsome man of middle years. Except for his mouth, and his eyes. "Which one, Lews Therin? You will not have anyone to help you this time. You are mine, or you are dead. In which case, you are mine anyway."

"laɪɝ!" ɹænd snɑɹəld. hi stʃɹʌk ət bælzəmən, bʌt ðə stæf ə tʃɑɹd wʊd tɝn ɪz bleɪɾ ɪn ə ʃaʊɝ ə spɑɹks. "fɑðɝ ə laɪz!"

"Liar!" Rand snarled. He struck at Ba'alzamon, but the staff of charred wood turned his blade in a shower of sparks. "Father of Lies!"

"ful! dɪd ðoʊz ʌðɝ fulz jə sʌmənd nɑt tɛl jə hu jə ɑɹ?" ðə faɪɝz ə bælzəmənz feɪs ɹɔɹd wɪð læftɝ.

"Fool! Did those other fools you summoned not tell you who you are?" The fires of Ba'alzamon's face roared with laughter.

ivən floʊɾɪŋ ɪn ɛmptinəs, ɹænd fɛlt ə tʃɪl. wəd ðeɪv laɪd? aɪ doʊnt wɑnə bi ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. hi fɝmd ɪz ɡɹɪp ɑn ɪz sɔɹd. pɑɹɾɪŋ ðə sɪlk, bʌt bælzəmən biɾ ɛvɹi kʌɾ əsaɪd; spɑɹks flu əz fɹəm ə blæksmɪθs fɔɹdʒ ən hæmɝ. "aɪ hæv bɪznəs ɪn fɑlm, ən nʌn wɪð ju. nɛvɝ wɪð ju," ɹænd sɛd. aɪ hæv tə hoʊld ɪz ətɛnʃən əntɪl ðeɪ kən fɹi ɛɡwin. ɪn ðəɾ ɑd weɪ, hi kəd si ðə bæɾəl ɹeɪdʒ əmʌŋ ðə fɑɡ-ʃɹaʊɾɪd wæɡən jɑɹdz ən hɔɹs lɑts.

Even floating in emptiness, Rand felt a chill. Would they have lied? I don't want to be the Dragon Reborn. He firmed his grip on his sword. Parting the Silk, but Ba'alzamon beat every cut aside; sparks flew as from a blacksmith's forge and hammer. "I have business in Falme, and none with you. Never with you," Rand said. I have to hold his attention until they can free Egwene. In that odd way, he could see the battle rage among the fog-shrouded wagon yards and horse lots.

"ju pɪɾəfəl ɹɛtʃ. juv saʊndəd ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ. jə ɑɹ lɪŋk tə ɪt, naʊ. dʒju θɪŋk ðə wɝmz ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ wɪl ɛvɝ ɹilis ju, naʊ? ðəl pʊt tʃeɪnz ɝaʊn jəɹ nɛk soʊ hɛvi jəl nɛvɝ kʌt ðɛm."

"You pitiful wretch. You have sounded the Horn of Valere. You are linked to it, now. Do you think the worms of the White Tower will ever release you, now? They will put chains around your neck so heavy you will never cut them."

ɹænd wɑz soʊ sɝpɹaɪzd i fɛlt ɪɾ ɪnsaɪd ðə vɔɪd. hi dʌznt noʊ ɛvɹiθɪŋ. hi dʌznt noʊ! hi wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪt mʌst ʃoʊ ɑn ɪz feɪs. tə kʌvɝ ɪt, hi ɹʌʃt ət bælzəmən. hʌmɪŋbɝd kɪsəz ðə hʌniɹoʊz. ðə mun ɑn ðə wɔɾɝ. ðə swɑloʊ ɹaɪdz ði ɛɹ. laɪtnɪŋ ɑɹtʃt bɪtwin sɔɹɾ ən stæf. kɔɹʌskeɪɾɪŋ ɡlɪɾɝ ʃaʊɝd ðə fɑɡ. jɛt bælzəmən fɛl bæk, hɪz aɪz bleɪzɪŋ ɪn fjʊɹiəs fɝnəsəz.

Rand was so surprised he felt it inside the void. He doesn't know everything. He doesn't know! He was sure it must show on his face. To cover it, he rushed at Ba'alzamon. Hummingbird Kisses the Honeyrose. The Moon on the Water. The Swallow Rides the Air. Lightning arched between sword and staff. Coruscating glitter showered the fog. Yet Ba'alzamon fell back, his eyes blazing in furious furnaces.

ət ði ɛdʒ ə hɪz əwɛɹnəs, ɹænd sɔ ðə sintʃæn fɔlɪŋ bæk ɪn ðə stʃɹits ə fɑlm, faɪɾɪŋ dɛspɝətli. deɪmeɪn tɔɹ ði ɝθ wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ, bʌɾ ɪt kəd nɑt hɑɹm ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ, nɔɹ ði ʌðɝ hɪɹoʊz ə ðə hɔɹn.

At the edge of his awareness, Rand saw the Seanchan falling back in the streets of Falme, fighting desperately. Damane tore the earth with the One Power, but it could not harm Artur Hawkwing, nor the other heroes of the Horn.

"wɪl jə ɹɪmeɪn ə slʌɡ bɪniθ ə ɹɑk?" bælzəmən snɑɹəld. ðə dɑɹknəs bɪhaɪn ɪm bɔɪld ən stɝd. "ju kɪl jɝsɛlf waɪl wi stæn hɪɹ. ðə paʊɝ ɹeɪdʒɪz ɪn ju. ɪt bɝnz ju. ɪts kɪlɪŋ ju! aɪ əloʊn ɪn ɔl ðə wɝl kən titʃ jə haʊ tə kəntʃɹoʊl ɪt. sɝv mi, ən laɪv. sɝv mi, əɹ daɪ!"

"Will you remain a slug beneath a rock?" Ba'alzamon snarled. The darkness behind him boiled and stirred. "You kill yourself while we stand here. The Power rages in you. It burns you. It is killing you! I alone in all the world can teach you how to control it. Serve me, and live. Serve me, or die!"

"nɛvɝ!" hæv tə hoʊld ɪm lɔŋ ɪnʌf. hɝi, hɔkwɪŋ. hɝi! hi lɔntʃt hɪmsɛlf ət bælzəmən əɡɛn. ðə dʌv teɪks flaɪt. ðə fɔlɪŋ lif.

"Never!" Have to hold him long enough. Hurry, Hawkwing. Hurry! He launched himself at Ba'alzamon again. The Dove Takes Flight. The Falling Leaf.

ðɪs taɪm ɪt wɑz i hu wɑz dʒɹɪvən bæk. dɪmli, hi sɔ ðə sintʃæn faɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ weɪ bæk ɪn əmʌŋ ðə steɪbəlz. hi ɹidʌbəld ɪz ɛfɝts. ðə kɪŋfɪʃɝ teɪks ə sɪlvɝbæk. ðə sintʃæn ɡeɪv weɪ tə ə tʃɑɹdʒ, ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ ən pɛɹɪn saɪd baɪ saɪɾ ɪn ðə væn. bʌndəlɪŋ stʃɹɔ. bælzəmən kɑɾ ɪz bloʊ ɪn ə faʊntən laɪk kɹɪmzən faɪɝəfliz, ən i hæd tə lip əweɪ bɪfɔɹ ðə stæf splɪɾ ɪz hɛd; ðə wɪn ə ðə bloʊ ɹʌfəld ɪz hɛɹ. ðə sintʃæn sɝdʒ fɔɹwɝd. stʃɹaɪkɪŋ ðə spɑɹk. spɑɹks flu laɪk heɪl, bælzəmən dʒʌmp fɹəm ɪz stʃɹoʊk, ən ðə sintʃæn wɝ dʒɹɪvən bæk tə ðə kɑbəlstoʊn stʃɹits.

This time it was he who was driven back. Dimly, he saw the Seanchan fighting their way back in among the stables. He redoubled his efforts. The Kingfisher Takes a Silverback. The Seanchan gave way to a charge, Artur Hawkwing and Perrin side by side in the van. Bundling Straw. Ba'alzamon caught his blow in a fountain like crimson fireflies, and he had to leap away before the staff split his head; the wind of the blow ruffled his hair. The Seanchan surged forward. Striking the Spark. Sparks flew like hail, Ba'alzamon jumped from his stroke, and the Seanchan were driven back to the cobblestone streets.

ɹænd wɑntəd tə haʊl əlaʊd. sʌɾənli hi nu ðət ðə tu bæɾəlz wɝ lɪŋkt. wən i ədvænst, ðə hɪɹoʊz kɔl baɪ ðə hɔɹn dʒɹoʊv ðə sintʃæn bæk; wən i fɛl bæk, ðə sintʃæn ɹoʊz ʌp.

Rand wanted to howl aloud. Suddenly he knew that the two battles were linked. When he advanced, the heroes called by the Horn drove the Seanchan back; when he fell back, the Seanchan rose up.

"ðeɪ wɪl nɑt seɪv ju," bælzəmən sɛd. "ðoʊz u maɪt seɪv jəl bi kæɹid fɑɹ əkɹɔs ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən. ɪf ɛvɝ jə si ðɛm əɡɛn, ðəl bi kɑlɝd sleɪvz, ən ðəl dɪstʃɹɔɪ jə fəɹ ðɛɹ nu mæstɝz."

"They will not save you," Ba'alzamon said. "Those who might save you will be carried far across the Aryth Ocean. If ever you see them again, they will be collared slaves, and they will destroy you for their new masters."

ɛɡwin. aɪ kæn lɛɾ əm də ðət tə hɝ.

Egwene. I can't let them do that to her.

bælzəmənz vɔɪs ɹoʊɾ oʊvɝ ɪz θɔts. "ju hæv oʊnli wʌn sælveɪʃən, ɹænd ælθɹ. luz θɝɪn kɪnsleɪɝ. aɪm jəɹ oʊnli sælveɪʃən. sɝv mi, ən əl ɡɪv jə ðə wɝld. ɹɪzɪst, ən əl dɪstʃɹɔɪ jə əz aɪ hæv soʊ ɔfən bɪfɔɹ. bʌt ðɪs taɪm əl dɪstʃɹɔɪ jə tə jəɹ vɛɹi soʊl, dɪstʃɹɔɪ jə ʌɾɝli ən fɝɛvɝ."

Ba'alzamon's voice rode over his thoughts. "You have only one salvation, Rand al'Thor. Lews Therin Kinslayer. I am your only salvation. Serve me, and I will give you the world. Resist, and I will destroy you as I have so often before. But this time I will destroy you to your very soul, destroy you utterly and forever."

aɪ hæv wʌn əɡɛn, luz θɝɪn. ðə θɔt wɑz bɪɑn ðə vɔɪd, jɛɾ ɪt tʊk ən ɛfɝt tə ɪɡnɔɹ ɪt, nɑt tə θɪŋk ʌv ɔl ðə laɪvz wɛɹ i hæd hɝɾ ɪt. hi ʃɪftəɾ ɪz sɔɹd, ən bælzəmən ɹɛɾid ɪz stæf.

I have won again, Lews Therin. The thought was beyond the void, yet it took an effort to ignore it, not to think of all the lives where he had heard it. He shifted his sword, and Ba'alzamon readied his staff.

fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm ɹænd ɹilaɪz ðət bælzəmən æktəɾ əz ɪf ðə hɛɹən-mɑɹk bleɪd kəd hɑɹm hɪm. stil kæn hɝt ðə dɑɹk wʌn. bʌt bælzəmən wɑtʃt ðə sɔɹd wɛɹəli. ɹænd wɑz wʌn wɪð ðə sɔɹd. hi kəd fil ɛvɹi pɑɹɾəkəl ʌv ɪt, taɪni bɪts ə θaʊzən taɪmz tu smɔl tə bi sin wɪð ði aɪ. ən i kəd fil ðə paʊɝ ðət səfjuzd ɪm ɹʌnɪŋ ɪndə ðə sɔɹd, əz wɛl, θɹɛɾɪŋ θɹu ði ɪntʃɹəkət meɪtʃɹɪsəz ɹɔt baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ə paʊɝ.

For the first time Rand realized that Ba'alzamon acted as if the heron-mark blade could harm him. Steel can't hurt the Dark One. But Ba'alzamon watched the sword warily. Rand was one with the sword. He could feel every particle of it, tiny bits a thousand times too small to be seen with the eye. And he could feel the Power that suffused him running into the sword, as well, threading through the intricate matrices wrought by Aes Sedai during the War of Power.

ɪt wɑz ənʌðɝ vɔɪs i hɝd ðɛn. lænz vɔɪs. ðəɹ wɪl kʌm ə taɪm wən jə wɑn sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ ðən jə wɑn laɪf. ɪŋtʃɹz vɔɪs. ɪts ɛvɹi mænz ɹaɪt tə tʃuz wən tə ʃið ðə sɔɹd. ðə pɪktʃɝ fɔɹmd ʌv ɛɡwin, kɑlɝd, lɪvɪŋ əɹ laɪf əz ə deɪmeɪn. θɹɛdz ə maɪ laɪf ɪn deɪnʒɝ. ɛɡwin. ɪf hɔkwɪŋ ɡɛts ɪndə fɑlm, hi kən seɪv hɝ. bɪfɔɹ i nu ɪt, hi hæd teɪkən ðə fɝs pəzɪʃən ə hɛɹən weɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə ɹʌʃəz, bælənst ɑn wʌn fʊt, sɔɹd ɹeɪz haɪ, oʊpən ən dɪfɛnsləs. dɛθ ɪz laɪɾɝ ðən ə fɛðɝ, duɾi hɛviɝ ðən ə maʊntən.

It was another voice he heard then. Lan's voice. There will come a time when you want something more than you want life. Ingtar's voice. It is every man's right to choose when to Sheathe the Sword. The picture formed of Egwene, collared, living her life as a damane. Threads of my life in danger. Egwene. If Hawkwing gets into Falme, he can save her. Before he knew it, he had taken the first position of Heron Wading in the Rushes, balanced on one foot, sword raised high, open and defenseless. Death is lighter than a feather, duty heavier than a mountain.

bælzəmən stɛɹɾ ət hɪm. "waɪ ɑɹ jə ɡɹɪnɪŋ laɪk ən ɪɾiət, ful? dʒju nɑt noʊ aɪ kən dɪstʃɹɔɪ jə ʌɾɝli?"

Ba'alzamon stared at him. "Why are you grinning like an idiot, fool? Do you not know I can destroy you utterly?"

ɹænd fɛlt ə kɑmnəs bɪɑn ðəɾ ə ðə vɔɪd. "aɪ wɪl nɛvɝ sɝv ju, fɑðɝ ə laɪz. ɪn ə θaʊzən laɪvz, aɪ nɛvɝ hæv. aɪ noʊ ðæt. aɪm ʃʊɹ ʌv ɪt. kʌm. ɪts taɪm tə daɪ."

Rand felt a calmness beyond that of the void. "I will never serve you, Father of Lies. In a thousand lives, I never have. I know that. I'm sure of it. Come. It is time to die."

bælzəmənz aɪz waɪɾənd; fəɹ ən ɪnstən ðeɪ wɝ fɝnəsəz ðət pʊt swɛɾ ɑn ɹændz feɪs. ðə blæknəs bɪhaɪn bælzəmən bɔɪld ʌp ɝaʊn hɪm, ən ɪz feɪs hɑɹɾənd. "ðɛn daɪ, wɝm!" hi stʃɹʌk wɪð ðə stæf, əz wɪð ə spɪɹ.

Ba'alzamon's eyes widened; for an instant they were furnaces that put sweat on Rand's face. The blackness behind Ba'alzamon boiled up around him, and his face hardened. "Then die, worm!" He struck with the staff, as with a spear.

ɹænd skɹimd əz i fɛlt ɪt pɪɹs ɪz saɪd, bɝnɪŋ laɪk ə waɪt-hɑt poʊkɝ. ðə vɔɪd tʃɹɛmbəld, bʌɾ i hɛld ɑn wɪð ðə læst ə hɪz stʃɹɛŋkθ, ən dʒɹoʊv ðə hɛɹən-mɑɹk bleɪɾ ɪndə bælzəmənz hɑɹt. bælzəmən skɹimd, ən ðə dɑɹk bɪhaɪn ɪm skɹimd. ðə wɝld ɪksploʊɾəd ɪn faɪɝ.

Rand screamed as he felt it pierce his side, burning like a white-hot poker. The void trembled, but he held on with the last of his strength, and drove the heron-mark blade into Ba'alzamon's heart. Ba'alzamon screamed, and the dark behind him screamed. The world exploded in fire.


tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾieɪt


CHAPTER 48

fɝs kleɪmɪŋ


First Claiming

mɪn stʃɹʌɡəld ʌp ðə kɑbəlstoʊn stʃɹit, pʊʃɪŋ θɹu kɹaʊdz ðət stʊd waɪt-feɪst ən stɛɹɪŋ, ðoʊz u wɝ nɑt skɹimɪŋ hɪstɛɹɪkli. ə fju ɹæn, simɪŋli wɪθaʊɾ ɛni aɪdiə ʌv wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ ɹʌnɪŋ, bʌt moʊs muv laɪk pʊɹli hændəl pʌpəts, mɔɹ əfɹeɪd tə ɡoʊ ðən tə steɪ. ʃi sɝtʃt ðə feɪsəz, hoʊpɪŋ tə faɪn ɛɡwin, əɹ ɪleɪn, əɹ nɪneɪiv, bʌɾ ɔl ʃi sɔ wɝ fɑlmɛn. ən ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ dʒɹɔɪŋ əɹ ɑn, əz ʃʊɹli əz ɪf ʃi hæɾ ə stʃɹɪŋ taɪd tə hɝ.

Min struggled up the cobblestone street, pushing through crowds that stood white-faced and staring, those who were not screaming hysterically. A few ran, seemingly without any idea of where they were running, but most moved like poorly handled puppets, more afraid to go than to stay. She searched the faces, hoping to find Egwene, or Elayne, or Nynaeve, but all she saw were Falmen. And there was something drawing her on, as surely as if she had a string tied to her.

wʌns ʃi tɝn tə lʊk bæk. sintʃæn ʃɪps bɝn ɪn ðə hɑɹbɝ, ən ʃi kəd si mɔɹ ɪn fleɪmz ɔf ðə hɑɹbɝ maʊð. mɛni skwɛɹɪʃ vɛsəlz wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi smɔl əɡɛns ðə sɛɾɪŋ sʌn, seɪlɪŋ wɛst əz fæst əz deɪmeɪn kəd meɪk ðə wɪnz dʒɹaɪv ðɛm, ən wʌn smɔl ʃɪp wɑz biɾɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðə hɑɹbɝ, tɪltɪŋ tə kætʃ ə wɪn tə teɪk ɪɾ əlɔŋ ðə koʊst. spɹeɪ. ʃi dɪd nɑt bleɪm beɪl doʊmən fəɹ nɑt weɪɾɪŋ lɔŋɡɝ, nɑɾ æftɝ wʌt ʃi hæd sin; ʃi θɔɾ ɪɾ ə wʌndɝ i hæd ɹɪmeɪn soʊ lɔŋ.

Once she turned to look back. Seanchan ships burned in the harbor, and she could see more in flames off the harbor mouth. Many squarish vessels were already small against the setting sun, sailing west as fast as damane could make the winds drive them, and one small ship was beating away from the harbor, tilting to catch a wind to take it along the coast. Spray. She did not blame Bayle Domon for not waiting longer, not after what she had seen; she thought it a wonder he had remained so long.

ðəɹ wɑz wʌn sintʃæn vɛsəl ɪn ðə hɑɹbɝ nɑt bɝnɪŋ, ðoʊ ɪts taʊɝz wɝ blæk fɹəm faɪɝz ɔlɹɛɾi ɪkstɪŋɡwɪʃt. əz ðə tɔl ʃɪp kɹɛp təwɔɹd ðə hɑɹbɝ maʊð, ə fɪɡjɝ ɑn hɔɹsbæk sʌɾənli əpɪɹɾ ɝaʊn ðə klɪfs skɝɾɪŋ ðə hɑɹbɝ. ɹaɪɾɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə wɔɾɝ. mɪnz maʊθ fɛl oʊpən. sɪlvɝ ɡlɪɾɝd əz ðə fɪɡjɝ ɹeɪzd ə baʊ; ə stʃɹik ə sɪlvɝ læns tə ðə bɑksi ʃɪp, ə ɡlimɪŋ laɪn kənɛktɪŋ baʊ ən ʃɪp. wɪð ə ɹɔɹ ʃi kəd hɪɹ ivən ət ðət dɪstəns, faɪɝ ɪnɡʌlf ðə fɔɹtaʊɝ ənu, ən seɪlɝz ɹʌʃt əbaʊt ðə dɛk.

There was one Seanchan vessel in the harbor not burning, though its towers were black from fires already extinguished. As the tall ship crept toward the harbor mouth, a figure on horseback suddenly appeared around the cliffs skirting the harbor. Riding across the water. Min's mouth fell open. Silver glittered as the figure raised a bow; a streak of silver lanced to the boxy ship, a gleaming line connecting bow and ship. With a roar she could hear even at that distance, fire engulfed the foretower anew, and sailors rushed about the deck.

mɪn blɪŋkt, ən wən ʃi lʊkt əɡɛn, ðə maʊntəd fɪɡjɝ wɑz ɡɔn. ðə ʃɪp stɪl sloʊli meɪd weɪ təwɔɹd ði oʊʃən, ðə kɹu faɪɾɪŋ ðə fleɪmz.

Min blinked, and when she looked again, the mounted figure was gone. The ship still slowly made way toward the ocean, the crew fighting the flames.

ʃi ɡeɪv hɝsɛlf ə ʃeɪk ən stɑɹɾəd tə klaɪm ðə stʃɹiɾ əɡɛn. ʃi hæd sin tu mʌtʃ ðət deɪ fəɹ sʌmwʌn ɹaɪɾɪŋ ə hɔɹs əkɹɔs wɔɾɝ tə bi mɔɹ ðən ə moʊməntɛɹi dɪstʃɹækʃən. ivən ɪf ɪt ɹɪli wɑz bɝdʒɪɾ ən əɹ baʊ. ən ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ. aɪ dɪd si hɪm. aɪ dɪd.

She gave herself a shake and started to climb the street again. She had seen too much that day for someone riding a horse across water to be more than a momentary distraction. Even if it really was Birgitte and her bow. And Artur Hawkwing. I did see him. I did.

ɪn fɹʌn ʌv wʌn ə ðə tɔl stoʊn bɪldɪŋz, ʃi stɑpt ənsɝteɪnli, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə pipəl u bɹʌʃt pæst əɹ əz ɪf stʌnd. ɪt wɑz ɪn ðɛɹ, sʌmwɛɹ, ðət ʃi hæd tə ɡoʊ. ʃi ɹʌʃt ʌp ðə stɛɹz ən pʊʃt oʊpən ðə dɔɹ.

In front of one of the tall stone buildings, she stopped uncertainly, ignoring the people who brushed past her as if stunned. It was in there, somewhere, that she had to go. She rushed up the stairs and pushed open the door.

noʊ wʌn tʃɹaɪd tə stɑp hɝ. əz fɑɹ əz ʃi kəd tɛl, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ wʌn ɪn ðə haʊs. moʊst ə fɑlm wɑz aʊɾ ɪn ðə stʃɹits, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dɪsaɪd wɛðɝ ðeɪ hæɾ ɔl ɡɔn mæd təɡɛðɝ. ʃi wɛn ɑn θɹu ðə haʊs, ɪndə ðə ɡɑɹɾən bɪhaɪnd, ən ðəɹ i wɑz.

No one tried to stop her. As far as she could tell, there was no one in the house. Most of Falme was out in the streets, trying to decide whether they had all gone mad together. She went on through the house, into the garden behind, and there he was.

ɹænd leɪ spɹɔld ɑn ɪz bæk ʌndɝ ən oʊk, feɪs peɪl ən aɪz kloʊzd, lɛf hænd ɡɹɪpɪŋ ə hɪl ðəɾ ɛndəɾ ɪn ə fʊɾ ə bleɪd ðəɾ əpɪɹd tə hæv bɪn mɛltəɾ ət ði ɛnd. hɪz tʃɛst ɹoʊz ən fɛl tu sloʊli, ən nɑt wɪð ðə ɹɛɡjəlɝ ɹɪðəm ə sʌmwʌn bɹiðɪŋ nɔɹməli.

Rand lay sprawled on his back under an oak, face pale and eyes closed, left hand gripping a hilt that ended in a foot of blade that appeared to have been melted at the end. His chest rose and fell too slowly, and not with the regular rhythm of someone breathing normally.

teɪkɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ tə kɑm hɝsɛlf, ʃi wɛn tə si wʌt ʃi kəd də fəɹ hɪm. fɝst wɑz tə ɡɛt ɹɪɾ ə ðət stʌb ʌv ə bleɪd; hi kəd hɝt hɪmsɛlf, əɹ hɝ, ɪf i stɑɹɾəd θɹæʃɪŋ. ʃi pɹaɪɾ ɪz hæn oʊpən, ən wɪnst wən ðə hɪl stʌk tə hɪz pɑm. ʃi tɔst ɪɾ əsaɪd wɪð ə ɡɹɪmɑs. ðə hɛɹən ɑn ðə hɪl hæd bɹændɪɾ ɪtsɛlf ɪndə hɪz hænd. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɑbviəs tə hɝ ðət ðət wɑz nɑt wʌt hæɾ ɪm laɪɪŋ ðəɹ ʌnkɑnʃəs. haʊ dɪɾ i kʌm baɪ ðæt? nɪneɪiv kən pʊɾ ə sɑv ɑn ɪt leɪɾɝ.

Taking a deep breath to calm herself, she went to see what she could do for him. First was to get rid of that stub of a blade; he could hurt himself, or her, if he started thrashing. She pried his hand open, and winced when the hilt stuck to his palm. She tossed it aside with a grimace. The heron on the hilt had branded itself into his hand. But it was obvious to her that that was not what had him lying there unconscious. How did he come by that? Nynaeve can put a salve on it later.

ə heɪsti ɪɡzæməneɪʃən ʃoʊd ðət moʊst ə hɪz kʌts ən bɹuzəz wɝ nɑt nu - ət list, ðə blʌd hæd hæd taɪm tə dʒɹaɪ ɪn ə kɹʌst, ən ðə bɹuzəz hæd stɑɹɾəd tə tɝn jɛloʊ ət ði ɛdʒəz - bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ə hoʊl bɝn θɹu hɪz koʊɾ ɑn ðə lɛf saɪd. oʊpənɪŋ ɪz koʊt, ʃi pʊld ʌp ɪz ʃɝt. bɹɛθ wɪsəl θɹu hɝ tiθ. ðəɹ wɑz ə waʊn bɝn ɪndə hɪz saɪd, bʌɾ ɪt hæd kɔɾɝaɪzd ɪtsɛlf. wʌt ʃʊk əɹ wɑz ðə fil ə hɪz flɛʃ. ɪt hæɾ ə tʌtʃ ʌv aɪs ɪn ɪt; hi meɪd ði ɛɹ sim wɔɹm.

A hasty examination showed that most of his cuts and bruises were not new - at least, the blood had had time to dry in a crust, and the bruises had started to turn yellow at the edges - but there was a hole burned through his coat on the left side. Opening his coat, she pulled up his shirt. Breath whistled through her teeth. There was a wound burned into his side, but it had cauterized itself. What shook her was the feel of his flesh. It had a touch of ice in it; he made the air seem warm.

ɡɹæbɪŋ ɪz ʃoʊldɝz, ʃi bɪɡæn tə dʒɹæɡ hɪm təwɔɹd ðə haʊs. hi hʌŋ lɪmp, ə dɛd weɪt. "ɡɹeɪt lʌmɑks," ʃi ɡɹʌntɪd. "ju kʊdn bi ʃɔɹt, ən laɪt, kəd ju? juv tə hæv ɔl ðət lɛɡ ən ʃoʊldɝ. aɪ ɔt tə lɛt jə laɪ aʊt hɪɹ."

Grabbing his shoulders, she began to drag him toward the house. He hung limp, a dead weight. "Great lummox," she grunted. "You couldn't be short, and light, could you? You have to have all that leg and shoulder. I ought to let you lie out here."

bʌt ʃi stʃɹʌɡəld ʌp ðə stɛps, kɛɹfəl nɑt tə bʌmp ɪm ɛni mɔɹ ðən ʃi kəɾ əvɔɪd, ən pʊld ɪm ɪnsaɪd. livɪŋ ɪm dʒʌst wɪðɪn ðə dɔɹ, ʃi nʌkəl ðə smɔl ə hɝ bæk, mʌɾɝɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf əbaʊt ðə pæɾɝn, ən meɪɾ ə heɪsti sɝtʃ. ðəɹ wɑz ə smɔl bɛdʒɹum ɪn ðə bæk ə ðə haʊs, pɝhæps ə sɝvəns ɹum, wɪð ə bɛd paɪl haɪ wɪð blæŋkəts, ən lɔɡz ɔlɹɛɾi leɪɾ ɑn ðə hɑɹθ. ɪn moʊməns, ʃi hæd ðə blæŋkəts θɹoʊn bæk ən ðə faɪɝ lɪt, əz wɛl əz ə læmp ɑn ðə bɛdsaɪd teɪbəl. ðən ʃi wɛn bæk fəɹ ɹænd.

But she struggled up the steps, careful not to bump him any more than she could avoid, and pulled him inside. Leaving him just within the door, she knuckled the small of her back, muttering to herself about the Pattern, and made a hasty search. There was a small bedroom in the back of the house, perhaps a servant's room, with a bed piled high with blankets, and logs already laid on the hearth. In moments, she had the blankets thrown back and the fire lit, as well as a lamp on the bedside table. Then she went back for Rand.

ɪt wɑz noʊ smɔl tæsk ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪm tə ðə ɹum, əɹ ʌp ɑntu ðə bɛd, bʌt ʃi mænədʒd ɪt wɪð oʊnli ə lɪɾəl hɑɹd bɹiðɪŋ, ən kʌvɝɾ ɪm ʌp. æftɝ ə moʊmənt, ʃi stʌk ə hæn ʌndɝ ðə blæŋkəts; ʃi wɪnst ən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. ðə ʃits wɝ aɪsi koʊld; hi hæd noʊ bɑɾi wɔɹmθ fəɹ ðə blæŋkəts tə hoʊld. wɪð ə pʊt-əpɑn saɪ, ʃi ɹɪəld ʌndɝ ðə kʌvɝz bɪsaɪd hɪm. faɪnəli, ʃi pʊɾ ɪz hɛɾ ɑn əɹ ɑɹm. hɪz aɪz wɝ stɪl kloʊzd, hɪz bɹiðɪŋ ɹæɡəd, bʌt ʃi θɔɾ i wəd bi dɛd baɪ ðə taɪm ʃi keɪm bæk ɪf ʃi lɛf tə faɪnd nɪneɪiv. hi nidz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, ʃi θɔt. ɔl aɪ kən də ɪz tʃɹaɪ tə ɡɪv ɪm ə lɪɾəl wɔɹmθ.

It was no small task getting him to the room, or up onto the bed, but she managed it with only a little hard breathing, and covered him up. After a moment, she stuck a hand under the blankets; she winced and shook her head. The sheets were icy cold; he had no body warmth for the blankets to hold. With a put-upon sigh, she wriggled under the covers beside him. Finally, she put his head on her arm. His eyes were still closed, his breathing ragged, but she thought he would be dead by the time she came back if she left to find Nynaeve. He needs an Aes Sedai, she thought. All I can do is try to give him a little warmth.

fəɹ ə taɪm ʃi stʌɾid ɪz feɪs. ɪt wɑz oʊnli hɪz feɪs ʃi sɔ; ʃi kəd nɛvɝ ɹɛɾ ɛniwʌn u wɑz nɑt kɑnʃəs. "aɪ laɪk oʊldɝ mɛn," ʃi toʊl hɪm. "aɪ laɪk mɛn wɪð ɛdʒəkeɪʃən, ən wɪt. aɪ hæv noʊ ɪntʃɹəst ɪn fɑɹmz, əɹ ʃip, əɹ ʃɛpɝdz. ɪspɛʃli bɔɪ ʃɛpɝdz." wɪð ə saɪ, ʃi smuð bæk ðə hɛɹ fɹəm ɪz feɪs; hi hæd sɪlki hɛɹ. "bʌt ðɛn, jə ɑɹən ə ʃɛpɝd, ɑɹ ju? nɑɾ ɛnimɔɹ. laɪt, waɪ dɪd ðə pæɾɝn əv tə kætʃ mi ʌp wɪð ju? waɪ kʊdn aɪ hæv sʌmθɪŋ seɪf ən sɪmpəl, laɪk biɪŋ ʃɪpɹɛkt wɪð noʊ fuɾ ən ə dʌzən hʌŋɡɹi ilmɛn?"

For a time she studied his face. It was only his face she saw; she could never read anyone who was not conscious. "I like older men," she told him. "I like men with education, and wit. I have no interest in farms, or sheep, or shepherds. Especially boy shepherds." With a sigh, she smoothed back the hair from his face; he had silky hair. "But then, you aren't a shepherd, are you? Not anymore. Light, why did the Pattern have to catch me up with you? Why couldn't I have something safe and simple, like being shipwrecked with no food and a dozen hungry Aielmen?"

ðəɹ wɑz ə saʊn ɪn ðə hɔl, ən ʃi ɹeɪzd əɹ hɛɾ əz ðə dɔɹ oʊpənd. ɛɡwin stʊd ðɛɹ, stɛɹɪŋ əɾ əm baɪ ðə laɪɾ ə ðə faɪɝ ən ðə læmp. "oʊ," wɑz ɔl ʃi sɛd.

There was a sound in the hall, and she raised her head as the door opened. Egwene stood there, staring at them by the light of the fire and the lamp. "Oh," was all she said.

mɪnz tʃiks kʌlɝd. waɪ æm aɪ bɪheɪvɪŋ laɪk aɪv dʌn sʌmθɪŋ ɹɔŋ? ful! "aɪ . . . aɪm kipɪŋ ɪm wɔɹm. hiz ʌnkɑnʃəs, ən hiz əz koʊld əz aɪs."

Min's cheeks colored. Why am I behaving like I've done something wrong? Fool! "I . . . I'm keeping him warm. He is unconscious, and he's as cold as ice."

ɛɡwin dɪd nɑt kʌm ɛni fɝðɝ ɪndə ðə ɹum. "aɪ - aɪ fɛlt ɪm pʊlɪŋ ət mi. niɾɪŋ mi. ɪleɪn fɛlt ɪt, tu. aɪ θɔɾ ɪt mʌs bi sʌmθɪŋ tə də wɪð - wɪð wʌɾ i ɪz, bʌt nɪneɪiv dɪdn fil ɛniθɪŋ." ʃi dʒɹu ə dip, ənstɛɾi bɹɛθ. "ɪleɪn ən nɪneɪiv ɑɹ ɡɛɾɪŋ ðə hɔɹsəz. wi faʊn bɛlə. ðə sintʃæn lɛf moʊst ə ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz bɪhaɪnd. nɪneɪiv sɛz wi ʃəd ɡoʊ əz sun əz wi kæn, ən - ænd. . . . mɪn, jə noʊ wʌɾ i ɪz, doʊn ju, naʊ?"

Egwene did not come any further into the room. "I - I felt him pulling at me. Needing me. Elayne felt it, too. I thought it must be something to do with - with what he is, but Nynaeve didn't feel anything." She drew a deep, unsteady breath. "Elayne and Nynaeve are getting the horses. We found Bela. The Seanchan left most of their horses behind. Nynaeve says we should go as soon as we can, and - and. . . . Min, you know what he is, don't you, now?"

"aɪ noʊ." mɪn wɑntəd tə teɪk əɹ ɑɹm fɹəm ʌndɝ ɹændz hɛd, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt meɪk hɝsɛlf muv. "aɪ θɪŋk aɪ du, ɛniweɪ. wʌtɛvɝ i ɪz, hiz hɝt. aɪ kən də nʌθɪŋ fəɹ ɪm ɪksɛp kip ɪm wɔɹm. meɪbi nɪneɪiv kæn."

"I know." Min wanted to take her arm from under Rand's head, but she could not make herself move. "I think I do, anyway. Whatever he is, he is hurt. I can do nothing for him except keep him warm. Maybe Nynaeve can."

"mɪn, jə noʊ . . . jə də noʊ ðəɾ i kænɑt mɛɹi. hi ɪzənt . . . seɪf . . . fəɹ ɛni ʌv ʌs, mɪn."

"Min, you know . . . you do know that he cannot marry. He isn't . . . safe . . . for any of us, Min."

"spik fəɹ jɝsɛlf," mɪn sɛd. ʃi pʊld ɹændz feɪs əɡɛnst əɹ bɹɛst. "ɪts laɪk ɪleɪn sɛd. jə tɔst ɪm əsaɪd fəɹ ðə waɪt taʊɝ. wʌt ʃəd jə kɛɹ ɪf aɪ pɪk ɪm ʌp?"

"Speak for yourself," Min said. She pulled Rand's face against her breast. "It's like Elayne said. You tossed him aside for the White Tower. What should you care if I pick him up?"

ɛɡwin lʊkt əɾ əɹ fəɹ wʌt simd ə lɔŋ taɪm. nɑɾ ət ɹænd, nɑɾ əɾ ɔl, oʊnli ət hɝ. ʃi fɛlt əɹ feɪs ɡɹoʊɪŋ hɑɾɝ ən wɑntəd tə lʊk əweɪ, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt.

Egwene looked at her for what seemed a long time. Not at Rand, not at all, only at her. She felt her face growing hotter and wanted to look away, but she could not.

"aɪ wɪl bɹɪŋ nɪneɪiv," ɛɡwin sɛd faɪnəli, ən wɔkt aʊɾ ə ðə ɹum wɪð əɹ bæk stʃɹeɪɾ ən əɹ hɛd haɪ.

"I will bring Nynaeve," Egwene said finally, and walked out of the room with her back straight and her head high.

mɪn wɑntəd tə kɔl aʊt, tə ɡoʊ æftɝ hɝ, bʌt ʃi leɪ ðəɹ əz ɪf fɹoʊzən. fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd tɪɹz stʌŋ əɹ aɪz. ɪts wʌɾ əz tə bi. aɪ noʊ ɪt. aɪ ɹɛɾ ɪɾ ɪn ɔl ə ðɛm. laɪt, aɪ doʊnt wɑnə bi pɑɹɾ ə ðɪs. "ɪts ɔl jəɹ fɔlt," ʃi toʊld ɹændz stɪl ʃeɪp. "noʊ, ɪɾ ɪzənt. bʌt jəl peɪ fəɹ ɪt, aɪ θɪŋk. wɝ ɔl kɑt laɪk flaɪz ɪn ə spaɪɾɝwɛb. wʌɾ ɪf aɪ toʊld əɹ ðɛɹz ənʌðɝ wʊmən jɛt tə kʌm, wʌn ʃi dʌzn ivən noʊ? fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, wʌt wəd jə θɪŋk ə ðæt, maɪ faɪn lɔɹd ʃɛpɝd? jə ɑɹən bæd-lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɔl, bʌt. . . . laɪt, aɪ doʊn ivən noʊ ɪf aɪm ðə wʌn jəl tʃuz. aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɪf aɪ wɑn jə tə tʃuz mi. əɹ wɪl jə tʃɹaɪ tə dændəl ɔl θɹi ʌv əs ɑn jəɹ ni? ɪt meɪ nɑt bi jəɹ fɔlt, ɹænd ælθɹ, bʌɾ ɪɾ ɪzən fɛɹ."

Min wanted to call out, to go after her, but she lay there as if frozen. Frustrated tears stung her eyes. It's what has to be. I know it. I read it in all of them. Light, I don't want to be part of this. "It's all your fault," she told Rand's still shape. "No, it isn't. But you will pay for it, I think. We're all caught like flies in a spiderweb. What if I told her there's another woman yet to come, one she doesn't even know? For that matter, what would you think of that, my fine Lord Shepherd? You aren't bad-looking at all, but. . . . Light, I don't even know if I am the one you'll choose. I don't know if I want you to choose me. Or will you try to dandle all three of us on your knee? It may not be your fault, Rand al'Thor, but it isn't fair."

"nɑt ɹænd ælθɹ," sɛɾ ə mjuzɪkəl vɔɪs fɹəm ðə dɔɹ. "luz θɝɪn tɛləmən. ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn."

"Not Rand al'Thor," said a musical voice from the door. "Lews Therin Telamon. The Dragon Reborn."

mɪn stɛɹd. ʃi wɑz ðə moʊs bjuɾəfəl wʊmən mɪn hæɾ ɛvɝ sin, wɪð peɪl, smuð skɪn, ən lɔŋ, blæk hɛɹ, ən aɪz əz dɑɹk əz naɪt. hɝ dʒɹɛs wɑz ə waɪt ðət wəd meɪk snoʊ sim dɪnʒi, bɛltəɾ ɪn sɪlvɝ. ɔl əɹ dʒuəlɹi wɑz sɪlvɝ. mɪn fɛl hɝsɛlf bɹɪsəl. "wʌt dʒju min? hu ɑɹ ju?"

Min stared. She was the most beautiful woman Min had ever seen, with pale, smooth skin, and long, black hair, and eyes as dark as night. Her dress was a white that would make snow seem dingy, belted in silver. All her jewelry was silver. Min felt herself bristle. "What do you mean? Who are you?"

ðə wʊmən keɪm tə stæn oʊvɝ ðə bɛd - hɝ muvməns wɝ soʊ ɡɹeɪsfəl, mɪn fɛlt ə stæb ʌv ɛnvi, ðoʊ ʃi hæd nɛvɝ bɪfɔɹ ɛnviɾ ɛni wʊmən ɛniθɪŋ - ən smuðd ɹændz hɛɹ əz ɪf mɪn wɝ nɑt ðɛɹ. "hi dʌzn bɪliv jɛt, aɪ θɪŋk. hi noʊz, bʌɾ i dʌz nɑt bɪliv. aɪ hæv ɡaɪɾəd ɪz stɛps, pʊʃt hɪm, pʊl hɪm, ɪntaɪs hɪm. hi wɑz ɔlweɪz stʌbɝn, bʌt ðɪs taɪm əl ʃeɪp hɪm. ɪʃəml θɪŋks i kəntʃɹoʊlz ɪvɛns, bʌɾ aɪ du." hɝ fɪŋɡɝ bɹʌʃt ɹændz fɔɹhɛɾ əz ɪf dʒɹɔɪŋ ə mɑɹk; mɪn θɔɾ ənizəli ðəɾ ɪt lʊk laɪk ðə dʒɹæɡənz fæŋ. ɹænd stɝd, mɝmɝɪŋ, ðə fɝst saʊn əɹ muvmən i hæd meɪd sɪns ʃi faʊn hɪm.

The woman came to stand over the bed - her movements were so graceful, Min felt a stab of envy, though she had never before envied any woman anything - and smoothed Rand's hair as if Min were not there. "He doesn't believe yet, I think. He knows, but he does not believe. I have guided his steps, pushed him, pulled him, enticed him. He was always stubborn, but this time I will shape him. Ishamael thinks he controls events, but I do." Her finger brushed Rand's forehead as if drawing a mark; Min thought uneasily that it looked like the Dragon's Fang. Rand stirred, murmuring, the first sound or movement he had made since she found him.

"hu ɑɹ ju?" mɪn dɪmændəd. ðə wʊmən lʊkt ət hɝ, oʊnli lʊkt, bʌt ʃi faʊn hɝsɛlf ʃɹɪŋkɪŋ bæk ɪndə ðə pɪloʊz, klʌtʃɪŋ ɹænd tə hɝ fɪɹsli.

"Who are you?" Min demanded. The woman looked at her, only looked, but she found herself shrinking back into the pillows, clutching Rand to her fiercely.

"aɪ æm kɔld lænfɝ, ɡɝl."

"I am called Lanfear, girl."

mɪnz maʊθ wɑz əbɹʌpli soʊ dʒɹaɪ ʃi kəd nɑɾ əv spoʊkən ɪf əɹ laɪf dɪpɛndəɾ ɑn ɪt. wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən! noʊ! laɪt, noʊ! ɔl ʃi kəd də wɑz ʃeɪk əɹ hɛd. ðə dɪnaɪəl meɪd lænfɝ smaɪl.

Min's mouth was abruptly so dry she could not have spoken if her life depended on it. One of the Forsaken! No! Light, no! All she could do was shake her head. The denial made Lanfear smile.

"luz θɝɪn wɑz ən ɪz maɪn, ɡɝl. tɛn ɪm wɛl fəɹ mi əntɪl aɪ kʌm fəɹ hɪm." ən ʃi wɑz ɡɔn.

"Lews Therin was and is mine, girl. Tend him well for me until I come for him." And she was gone.

mɪn ɡeɪpt. wʌn moʊmənt ʃi wɑz ðɛɹ, ðən ʃi wɑz ɡɔn. mɪn dɪskʌvɝd ʃi wɑz hʌɡɪŋ ɹændz ʌnkɑnʃəs fɔɹm taɪtli. ʃi wɪʃt ʃi dɪd nɑt fil əz ɪf ʃi wɑntəɾ ɪm tə pɹətɛk hɝ.

Min gaped. One moment she was there, then she was gone. Min discovered she was hugging Rand's unconscious form tightly. She wished she did not feel as if she wanted him to protect her.

ɡɔn feɪs sɛt wɪð ɡɹɪm pɝpəs, baɪɑɝ ɡæləpt wɪð ðə sɪŋkɪŋ sʌn bɪhaɪn ɪm ən nɛvɝ lʊk bæk. hi hæd sin ɔl i niɾəd tə, ɔl i kəd wɪð ðəɾ əkɝs fɑɡ. ðə lidʒən wɑz dɛd, lɔɹd kæptən dʒɛəfɹæm bɔɹnhəld wɑz dɛd, ən ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli wʌn ɛkspləneɪʃən fəɹ ðæt; dɑɹkfɹɛnz hæd bɪtʃɹeɪd ðɛm, dɑɹkfɹɛnz laɪk ðət pɛɹɪn ə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. ðət wɝɾ i hæd tə kæɹi tə deɪn bɔɹnhəld, ðə lɔɹd kæptənz sʌn, wɪð ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt wɑtʃɪŋ tɑɹ vəlɑn. bʌɾ i hæd wɝs tə tɛl, ən tə nʌn lɛs ðən peɪdʒɹən naɪl hɪmsɛlf. hi hæd tə tɛl wʌɾ i hæd sin ɪn ðə skaɪ əbʌv fɑlm. hi flɑɡd ɪz hɔɹs wɪð ɪz ɹeɪnz ən nɛvɝ lʊk bæk.

Gaunt face set with grim purpose, Byar galloped with the sinking sun behind him and never looked back. He had seen all he needed to, all he could with that accursed fog. The legion was dead, Lord Captain Geofram Bornhald was dead, and there was only one explanation for that; Darkfriends had betrayed them, Darkfriends like that Perrin of the Two Rivers. That word he had to carry to Dain Bornhald, the Lord Captain's son, with the Children of the Light watching Tar Valon. But he had worse to tell, and to none less than Pedron Niall himself. He had to tell what he had seen in the sky above Falme. He flogged his horse with his reins and never looked back.


tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾinaɪn


CHAPTER 49

wʌt wɑz mɛn tə bi


What Was Meant to Be

ɹænd oʊpən ɪz aɪz ən faʊn hɪmsɛlf stɛɹɪŋ ʌp ət sʌnlaɪt slæntɪŋ θɹu ðə bɹæntʃəz ʌv ə lɛðɝlif, ɪts bɹɔd, tʌf livz stɪl ɡɹin dɪspaɪt ðə taɪm ə jɪɹ. ðə wɪn stɝɪŋ ðə livz kæɹiɾ ə hɪn ə snoʊ, kʌm naɪtfɔl. hi leɪ ɑn ɪz bæk, ən i kəd fil blæŋkəts kʌvɝɪŋ ɪm ʌndɝ ɪz hænz. hɪz koʊɾ ən ʃɝt sim tə bi ɡɔn, bʌt sʌmθɪŋ wɑz baɪndɪŋ ɪz tʃɛst, ən ɪz lɛf saɪd hɝt. hi tɝn ɪz hɛd, ən mɪn wɑz sɪɾɪŋ ðəɹ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm. hi ɔlmoʊs dɪd nɑt noʊ hɝ, wɛɹɪŋ skɝts. ʃi smaɪld ənsɝteɪnli.

Rand opened his eyes and found himself staring up at sunlight slanting through the branches of a leatherleaf, its broad, tough leaves still green despite the time of year. The wind stirring the leaves carried a hint of snow, come nightfall. He lay on his back, and he could feel blankets covering him under his hands. His coat and shirt seemed to be gone, but something was binding his chest, and his left side hurt. He turned his head, and Min was sitting there on the ground, watching him. He almost did not know her, wearing skirts. She smiled uncertainly.

"mɪn. ɪts ju. wɛɹ dɪd jə kʌm fɹʌm? wɛɹ ɑɹ wi?" hɪz mɛmɹi keɪm ɪn flæʃɪz ən pætʃəz. oʊl θɪŋz i kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ, bʌt ðə læs fju deɪz sim laɪk bɪts ə bɹoʊkən mɪɹɝ, spɪnɪŋ θɹu hɪz maɪnd, ʃoʊɪŋ ɡlɪmpsɪz ðət wɝ ɡɔn bɪfɔɹ i kəd si ðɛm klɪɹli.

"Min. It is you. Where did you come from? Where are we?" His memory came in flashes and patches. Old things he could remember, but the last few days seemed like bits of broken mirror, spinning through his mind, showing glimpses that were gone before he could see them clearly.

"fɹʌm fɑlm," ʃi sɛd. "wɝ faɪv deɪz ist ə ðɛɹ, naʊ, ən juv bɪn əslip ɔl ðət taɪm."

"From Falme," she said. "We're five days east of there, now, and you've been asleep all that time."

"fɑlm." mɔɹ mɛmɹi. mæt hæd bloʊn ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ. "ɛɡwin! ɪz ʃi . . . ? dɪd ðeɪ fɹi hɝ?" hi hɛld ɪz bɹɛθ.

"Falme." More memory. Mat had blown the Horn of Valere. "Egwene! Is she . . . ? Did they free her?" He held his breath.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt 'ðeɪ' jə min, bʌt ʃiz fɹi. wi fɹiɾ əɹ aʊɝsɛlvz."

"I don't know what 'they' you mean, but she's free. We freed her ourselves."

"wi? aɪ doʊn ʌndɝstænd." ʃiz fɹi. ət list ʃiz -  "nɪneɪiv, ən ɪleɪn, ən mi."

"We? I don't understand." She's free. At least she is -  "Nynaeve, and Elayne, and me."

"nɪneɪiv? ɪleɪn? haʊ? jə wɝ ɔl ɪn fɑlm?" hi stʃɹʌɡəl tə sɪɾ ʌp, bʌt ʃi pʊʃt ɪm bæk daʊn izəli ən steɪd ðɛɹ, hænz ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝz, aɪz ɪntɛn ɑn ɪz feɪs. "wɛɹ ɪz ʃi?"

"Nynaeve? Elayne? How? You were all in Falme?" He struggled to sit up, but she pushed him back down easily and stayed there, hands on his shoulders, eyes intent on his face. "Where is she?"

"ɡɔn." mɪnz feɪs kʌlɝd. "ðeɪɹ ɔl ɡɔn. ɛɡwin, ən nɪneɪiv, ən mæt, ən hʊɹɪn, ən vɛɹɪn. hʊɹɪn dɪdnt wɑnə liv ju, ɹɪli. ðəɹ ɑn ðɛɹ weɪ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn. ɛɡwin ən nɪneɪiv bæk tə ðɛɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ɪn ðə taʊɝ, ən mæt fəɹ wʌtɛvɝ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hæv tə də əbaʊt ðət dæɡɝ. ðeɪ tʊk ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ wɪð ðɛm. aɪ kæn bɪliv aɪ æktʃəli  sɔ ɪt."

"Gone." Min's face colored. "They're all gone. Egwene, and Nynaeve, and Mat, and Hurin, and Verin. Hurin didn't want to leave you, really. They're on their way to Tar Valon. Egwene and Nynaeve back to their training in the Tower, and Mat for whatever the Aes Sedai have to do about that dagger. They took the Horn of Valere with them. I can't believe I actually saw it."

"ɡɔn," hi mʌɾɝd. "ʃi dɪdn ivən weɪt tɪl aɪ woʊk ʌp." ðə ɹɛɾ ɪn mɪnz tʃiks dipənd, ən ʃi sæt bæk, stɛɹɪŋ əɾ əɹ læp.

"Gone," he muttered. "She didn't even wait till I woke up." The red in Min's cheeks deepened, and she sat back, staring at her lap.

hi ɹeɪzd ɪz hænz tə ɹʌn əm oʊvɝ ɪz feɪs, ən stɑpt, stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪz pɑmz ɪn ʃɑk. ðəɹ wɑz ə hɛɹən bɹændɪɾ əkɹɔs ɪz lɛf pɑm, tu, naʊ, tə mætʃ ðə wʌn ɑn ɪz ɹaɪt, ɛvɹi laɪn klin ən tʃɹu. wʌns ðə hɛɹən tə sɛɾ ɪz pæθ; twaɪs ðə hɛɹən tə neɪm ɪm tʃɹu. "noʊ!"

He raised his hands to run them over his face, and stopped, staring at his palms in shock. There was a heron branded across his left palm, too, now, to match the one on his right, every line clean and true. Once the heron to set his path; Twice the heron to name him true. "No!"

"ðeɪ ɑɹ ɡɔn," ʃi sɛd. "seɪɪŋ 'noʊ' woʊn tʃeɪnʒ ɪt."

"They are gone," she said. "Saying 'no' won't change it."

hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. sʌmθɪŋ toʊld ɪm ðə peɪn ɪn ɪz saɪd wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt. hi kəd nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ biɪŋ ɪnʒɝd, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt. hi stɑɹɾəd tə lɪft ɪz blæŋkəts tə lʊk, bʌt ʃi slæpt ɪz hænz əweɪ.

He shook his head. Something told him the pain in his side was important. He could not remember being injured, but it was important. He started to lift his blankets to look, but she slapped his hands away.

"ju kæn də ɛni ɡʊd wɪð ðæt. ɪɾ ɪzən hild ɔl ðə weɪ, jɛt. vɛɹɪn tʃɹaɪd hilɪŋ, bʌt ʃi sɛɾ ɪt dɪdnt wɝk ðə weɪ ɪt ʃʊd." ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, nɪbəlɪŋ əɹ lɪp. "mɔɪɹeɪn sɛz nɪneɪiv mʌst əv dʌn sʌmθɪŋ, əɹ jə wʊdn əv lɪv tɪl wi kæɹid jə tə vɛɹɪn, bʌt nɪneɪiv sɛz ʃi wɑz tu fɹaɪɾənd tə laɪɾ ə kændəl. ðəɹ ɪz . . . sʌmθɪŋ ɹɔŋ wɪð jəɹ waʊnd. jəl əv tə weɪt fəɹ ɪt tə hil nætʃɹəli." ʃi sim tʃɹʌbəld.

"You can't do any good with that. It isn't healed all the way, yet. Verin tried Healing, but she said it didn't work the way it should." She hesitated, nibbling her lip. "Moiraine says Nynaeve must have done something, or you wouldn't have lived till we carried you to Verin, but Nynaeve says she was too frightened to light a candle. There is . . . something wrong with your wound. You will have to wait for it to heal naturally." She seemed troubled.

"mɔɪɹeɪn ɪz hɪɹ?" hi bɑɹkt ə bɪɾɝ læf. "wɛn jə sɛd vɛɹɪn wɑz ɡɔn, aɪ θɔɾ aɪ wɑz fɹi ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ əɡɛn."

"Moiraine is here?" He barked a bitter laugh. "When you said Verin was gone, I thought I was free of Aes Sedai again."

"aɪ æm hɪɹ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. ʃi əpɪɹd, ɔl ɪn blu ən əz sɝin əz ɪf ʃi stʊɾ ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, stʃɹoʊlɪŋ ʌp tə stæn oʊvɝ hɪm. mɪn wɑz fɹaʊnɪŋ ət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɹænd hæd ði ɑd filɪŋ ðət ʃi mɛn tə pɹətɛkt ɪm fɹəm mɔɪɹeɪn.

"I am here," Moiraine said. She appeared, all in blue and as serene as if she stood in the White Tower, strolling up to stand over him. Min was frowning at the Aes Sedai. Rand had the odd feeling that she meant to protect him from Moiraine.

"aɪ wɪʃ jə wɝn hɪɹ," hi toʊl ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. "æz fɑɹ əz aɪm kənsɝnd, jə kən ɡoʊ bæk tə wɛɹɛvɝ juv bɪn haɪɾɪŋ ən steɪ ðɛɹ."

"I wish you weren't here," he told the Aes Sedai. "As far as I am concerned, you can go back to wherever you've been hiding and stay there."

"aɪ hæv nɑt bɪn haɪɾɪŋ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd kɑmli. "aɪ hæv bɪn duɪŋ wʌɾ aɪ kʊd, hɪɹ ɑn toʊmən hɛd, ən ɪn fɑlm. ɪt wɑz lɪɾəl ɪnʌf, ðoʊ aɪ lɝn mʌtʃ. aɪ feɪl tə ɹɛskju tu ʌv maɪ sɪstɝz bɪfɔɹ ðə sintʃæn hɝɾɪd əm ɑntu ðə ʃɪps wɪð ðə liʃt wʌnz, bʌɾ aɪ dɪd wʌɾ aɪ kʊd."

"I have not been hiding," Moiraine said calmly. "I have been doing what I could, here on Toman Head, and in Falme. It was little enough, though I learned much. I failed to rescue two of my sisters before the Seanchan herded them onto the ships with the Leashed Ones, but I did what I could."

"wʌt jə kʊd. jə sɛn vɛɹɪn tə ʃɛpɝd mi, bʌɾ ɪm noʊ ʃip, mɔɪɹeɪn. jə sɛɾ aɪ kəd ɡoʊ wɛɹ aɪ wɑntəd, ən aɪ min tə ɡoʊ wɛɹ jə ɑɹ nɑt."

"What you could. You sent Verin to shepherd me, but I'm no sheep, Moiraine. You said I could go where I wanted, and I mean to go where you are not."

"aɪ dɪd nɑt sɛn vɛɹɪn." mɔɪɹeɪn fɹaʊnd. "ʃi dɪd ðəɾ ɑn əɹ oʊn. jə ɑɹ ʌv ɪntʃɹəs tə ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni pipəl, ɹænd. dɪd feɪn faɪn ju, əɹ jə hɪm?"

"I did not send Verin." Moiraine frowned. "She did that on her own. You are of interest to a great many people, Rand. Did Fain find you, or you him?"

ðə sʌɾən tʃeɪnʒ ə tɑpɪk tʊk ɪm baɪ sɝpɹaɪz. "feɪn? noʊ. ə faɪn hɪɹoʊ aɪ meɪk. aɪ tʃɹaɪd tə ɹɛskju ɛɡwin, ən mɪn dɪɾ ɪt bɪfɔɹ mi. feɪn sɛɾ i wəd hɝɾ ɛmənz fild ɪf aɪ dɪdn feɪs hɪm, ən aɪ nɛvɝ leɪɾ aɪz ɑn hɪm. dɪɾ i ɡoʊ wɪð ðə sintʃæn, tu?"

The sudden change of topic took him by surprise. "Fain? No. A fine hero I make. I tried to rescue Egwene, and Min did it before me. Fain said he would hurt Emond's Field if I didn't face him, and I never laid eyes on him. Did he go with the Seanchan, too?"

mɔɪɹeɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "aɪ də nɑt noʊ. aɪ wɪʃ aɪ dɪd. bʌɾ ɪts əz wɛl jə dɪd nɑt faɪn hɪm, nɑɾ əntɪl jə noʊ wʌɾ i ɪz, ət list."

Moiraine shook her head. "I do not know. I wish I did. But it is as well you did not find him, not until you know what he is, at least."

"hiz ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd."

"He's a Darkfriend."

"mɔɹ ðən ðæt. wɝs ðən ðæt. pdən feɪn wɑz ðə dɑɹk wʌnz kɹitʃɝ tə ðə dɛpθs ə hɪz soʊl, bʌɾ aɪ bɪliv ðəɾ ɪn ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ i fɛl əfaʊl ə mɔɹɾɪθ, hu wɑz əz vaɪl ɪn faɪɾɪŋ ðə ʃædoʊ əz ɛvɝ ðə ʃædoʊ ɪtsɛlf wɑz. mɔɹɾɪθ tʃɹaɪd tə kənsum feɪnz soʊl, tə hæv ə hjumən bɑɾi əɡɛn, bʌt faʊn ə soʊl ðət hæd bɪn tʌtʃt dɝɛkli baɪ ðə dɑɹk wʌn, ən wʌt ɹɪzʌltɪd. . . . wʌt ɹɪzʌltɪd wɑz niðɝ pdən feɪn nɔɹ mɔɹɾɪθ, bʌt sʌmθɪŋ fɑɹ mɔɹ ivəl, ə blɛn ə ðə tu. feɪn - lɛɾ əs kɔl ɪm ðət - ɪz mɔɹ deɪnʒɝəs ðən jə kən bɪliv. jə maɪt nɑɾ əv sɝvaɪv sətʃ ə miɾɪŋ, ən ɪf jə hæd, jə maɪɾ əv bɪn wɝs ðən tɝn tə ðə ʃædoʊ."

"More than that. Worse than that. Padan Fain was the Dark One's creature to the depths of his soul, but I believe that in Shadar Logoth he fell afoul of Mordeth, who was as vile in fighting the Shadow as ever the Shadow itself was. Mordeth tried to consume Fain's soul, to have a human body again, but found a soul that had been touched directly by the Dark One, and what resulted. . . . What resulted was neither Padan Fain nor Mordeth, but something far more evil, a blend of the two. Fain - let us call him that - is more dangerous than you can believe. You might not have survived such a meeting, and if you had, you might have been worse than turned to the Shadow."

"ɪf hiz əlaɪv, ɪf i dɪd nɑt ɡoʊ wɪð ðə sintʃæn, aɪ hæv tə - " hi kʌɾ ɔf əz ʃi pɹədust ɪz hɛɹən-mɑɹk sɔɹd fɹəm ʌndɝ əɹ kloʊk. ðə bleɪɾ ɛndəɾ əbɹʌpli ə fʊt fɹəm ðə hɪlt, əz ɪf ɪt hæd bɪn mɛltəd. mɛmɹi keɪm kɹæʃɪŋ bæk. "aɪ kɪl hɪm," hi sɛd sɔfli. "ðɪs taɪm aɪ kɪl hɪm."

"If he is alive, if he did not go with the Seanchan, I have to - " He cut off as she produced his heron-mark sword from under her cloak. The blade ended abruptly a foot from the hilt, as if it had been melted. Memory came crashing back. "I killed him," he said softly. "This time I killed him."

mɔɪɹeɪn pʊt ðə ɹuən sɔɹɾ əsaɪd laɪk ðə jusləs θɪŋ ɪt naʊ wɑz, ən waɪpt əɹ hænz təɡɛðɝ. "ðə dɑɹk wʌn ɪz nɑt sleɪn soʊ izəli. ðə mɪɹ fæk ðəɾ i əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə skaɪ əbʌv fɑlm ɪz mɔɹ ðən mɪɹli tʃɹʌbəlɪŋ. hi ʃəd nɑt bi eɪbəl tə də ðæt, ɪf hiz baʊn əz wi bɪliv. ən ɪf hiz nɑt, waɪ hæz i nɑt dɪstʃɹɔɪɾ əs ɔl?" mɪn stɝɾ ənizəli.

Moiraine put the ruined sword aside like the useless thing it now was, and wiped her hands together. "The Dark One is not slain so easily. The mere fact that he appeared in the sky above Falme is more than merely troubling. He should not be able to do that, if he is bound as we believe. And if he is not, why has he not destroyed us all?" Min stirred uneasily.

"ɪn ðə skaɪ?" ɹænd sɛɾ ɪn wʌndɝ.

"In the sky?" Rand said in wonder.

"boʊθ ə ju," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "jɔɹ bæɾəl tʊk pleɪs əkɹɔs ðə skaɪ, ɪn fʊl vju ʌv ɛvɹi soʊl ɪn fɑlm. pɝhæps ɪn ʌðɝ taʊnz ɑn toʊmən hɛd, tu, ɪf hæf wʌɾ aɪ hɪɹ ɪz tə bi bɪlivd."

"Both of you," Moiraine said. "Your battle took place across the sky, in full view of every soul in Falme. Perhaps in other towns on Toman Head, too, if half what I hear is to be believed."

"wi - wi sɔ ɪɾ ɔl," mɪn sɛɾ ɪn ə feɪn vɔɪs. ʃi pʊɾ ə hæn oʊvɝ wʌn ə ɹændz kʌmfɝɾɪŋli.

"We - we saw it all," Min said in a faint voice. She put a hand over one of Rand's comfortingly.

mɔɪɹeɪn ɹitʃt ʌndɝ əɹ kloʊk əɡɛn ən keɪm aʊt wɪð ə ɹoʊl pɑɹtʃmənt, wʌn ə ðə lɑɹdʒ ʃits sətʃ əz ðə stʃɹiɾ ɑɹɾəsts ɪn fɑlm juzd. ðə tʃɔks wɝ ə lɪɾəl smʌdʒd wən ʃi ənfɝld ɪt, bʌt ðə pɪktʃɝ wɑz stɪl klɪɹ ɪnʌf. ə mæn huz feɪs wɑz ə sɑləd fleɪm fɔt wɪð ə stæf əɡɛnst ənʌðɝ wɪð ə sɔɹɾ əmʌŋ klaʊdz wɛɹ laɪtnɪŋ dænst, ən bɪhaɪn əm ɹɪpəl ðə dʒɹæɡən bænɝ. ɹændz feɪs wɑz izəli ɹɛkəɡnaɪzəbəl.

Moiraine reached under her cloak again and came out with a rolled parchment, one of the large sheets such as the street artists in Falme used. The chalks were a little smudged when she unfurled it, but the picture was still clear enough. A man whose face was a solid flame fought with a staff against another with a sword among clouds where lightning danced, and behind them rippled the Dragon banner. Rand's face was easily recognizable.

"haʊ mɛni hæv sin ðæt?" hi dɪmændəd. "tɛɹ ɪɾ ʌp. bɝn ɪt."

"How many have seen that?" he demanded. "Tear it up. Burn it."

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ lɛt ðə pɑɹtʃmən ɹoʊl bæk ʌp. "ɪt wəd də noʊ ɡʊd, ɹænd. aɪ bɑt ðət tu deɪz ɡɔn, ɪn ə vɪlədʒ wi pæs θɹu. ðəɹ ɑɹ hʌnʒɹədz ə ðɛm, pɝhæps θaʊzənz, ən ðə teɪl ɪz biɪŋ toʊld ɛvɹiwɛɹ ə haʊ ðə dʒɹæɡən bæɾəld ðə dɑɹk wʌn ɪn ðə skaɪz əbʌv fɑlm."

The Aes Sedai let the parchment roll back up. "It would do no good, Rand. I bought that two days gone, in a village we passed through. There are hundreds of them, perhaps thousands, and the tale is being told everywhere of how the Dragon battled the Dark One in the skies above Falme."

ɹænd lʊkt ət mɪn. ʃi nɑɾəd ɹɪlʌktənli, ən skwizd ɪz hænd. ʃi lʊk fɹaɪɾənd, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt flɪntʃ əweɪ. aɪ wʌndɝ ɪf ðæts waɪ ɛɡwin lɛft. ʃi wɑz ɹaɪt tə liv.

Rand looked at Min. She nodded reluctantly, and squeezed his hand. She looked frightened, but she did not flinch away. I wonder if that's why Egwene left. She was right to leave.

"ðə pæɾɝn wivz ɪtsɛlf ɝaʊn jə ivən mɔɹ taɪtli," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "ju nid mi naʊ mɔɹ ðən ɛvɝ."

"The Pattern weaves itself around you even more tightly," Moiraine said. "You need me now more than ever."

"aɪ doʊnt nid ju," hi sɛd hɑɹʃli, "æn aɪ doʊnt wɑn ju. əl nɑɾ əv ɛniθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðɪs." hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd biɪŋ kɔld luz θɝɪn; nɑɾ oʊnli baɪ bælzəmən, bʌt baɪ ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ. "aɪ woʊnt. laɪt, ðə dʒɹæɡən ɪz səpoʊz tə bɹeɪk ðə wɝld əɡɛn, tə tɛɹ ɛvɹiθɪŋ əpɑɹt. əl nɑt bi ðə dʒɹæɡən."

"I don't need you," he said harshly, "and I don't want you. I will not have anything to do with this." He remembered being called Lews Therin; not only by Ba'alzamon, but by Artur Hawkwing. "I won't. Light, the Dragon is supposed to Break the World again, to tear everything apart. I will not be the Dragon."

"ju ɑɹ wʌt jə ɑɹ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "ɔlɹɛɾi jə stɝ ðə wɝld. ðə blæk ədʒɑ hæz ɹɪvild ɪtsɛlf fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm ɪn tu θaʊzən jɪɹz. ɑɹæd dumən ən tæɹɑbən wɝ ɑn ðə bɹɪŋk ʌv wɔɹ, ən ɪɾəl bi wɝs wən nuz ə fɑlm ɹitʃəz ðɛm. kɛɹhin ɪz ɪn sɪvəl wɔɹ."

"You are what you are," Moiraine said. "Already you stir the world. The Black Ajah has revealed itself for the first time in two thousand years. Arad Doman and Tarabon were on the brink of war, and it will be worse when news of Falme reaches them. Cairhien is in civil war."

"aɪ dɪd nʌθɪŋ ɪn kɛɹhin," hi pɹətɛstəd. "ju kæn bleɪm ðəɾ ɑn mi."

"I did nothing in Cairhien," he protested. "You can't blame that on me."

"duɪŋ nʌθɪŋ wɑz ɔlweɪz ə plɔɪ ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪt ɡeɪm," ʃi sɛd wɪð ə saɪ, "æn ɪspɛʃli əz ðeɪ pleɪ ɪt naʊ. jə wɝ ðə spɑɹk, ən kɛɹhin ɪksploʊɾəd laɪk ən ɪluməneɪɾɝz faɪɝwɝk. wʌt dʒju θɪŋk wɪl hæpən wən wɝɾ ə fɑlm ɹitʃəz ɑɹæd dumən ən tæɹɑbən? ðəɹ əv ɔlweɪz bɪn mɛn wɪlɪŋ tə pɹoʊkleɪm fəɹ ɛni mæn u kɔl hɪmsɛlf ðə dʒɹæɡən, bʌt ðeɪv nɛvɝ bɪfɔɹ hæd sətʃ saɪnz əz ðɪs. ðəɹ ɪz mɔɹ. hɪɹ." ʃi tɔst ə paʊtʃ ɑn ɪz tʃɛst.

"Doing nothing was always a ploy in the Great Game," she said with a sigh, "and especially as they play it now. You were the spark, and Cairhien exploded like an Illuminator's firework. What do you think will happen when word of Falme reaches Arad Doman and Tarabon? There have always been men willing to proclaim for any man who called himself the Dragon, but they have never before had such signs as this. There is more. Here." She tossed a pouch on his chest.

hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd ə moʊmən bɪfɔɹ oʊpənɪŋ ɪt. wɪðɪn leɪ ʃɑɹdz ʌv wʌt sim tə bi blæk-ænd-waɪt ɡleɪz pɑɾɝi. hi hæd sin ðɛɹ laɪk bɪfɔɹ. "ənʌðɝ sil ɑn ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən," hi mʌmbəld. mɪn ɡæspt; hɝ ɡɹɪp ɑn ɪz hæn sɔt kʌmfɝt, naʊ, ɹæðɝ ðən ɔfɝɪŋ ɪt.

He hesitated a moment before opening it. Within lay shards of what seemed to be black-and-white glazed pottery. He had seen their like before. "Another seal on the Dark One's prison," he mumbled. Min gasped; her grip on his hand sought comfort, now, rather than offering it.

"tu," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd.
