"θɹi ʌv ðə sɛvən ɑɹ bɹoʊkən naʊ. ðə wʌn aɪ hæd, ən tu aɪ faʊn ɪn ðə haɪ lɔɹdz dwɛlɪŋ ɪn fɑlm. wən ɔl sɛvən ɑɹ bɹoʊkən, pɝhæps ivən bɪfɔɹ, ðə pætʃ mɛn pʊɾ oʊvɝ ðə hoʊl ðeɪ dʒɹɪld ɪndə ðə pɹɪzən ðə kɹieɪɾɝ meɪd wɪl bi tɔɹn əsʌndɝ, ən ðə dɑɹk wʌn wɪl wʌns mɔɹ bi eɪbəl tə pʊɾ ɪz hæn θɹu ðət hoʊl ən tʌtʃ ðə wɝld. ən ði oʊnli hoʊp ə ðə wɝld ɪz ðət ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɪl bi ðəɹ tə feɪs hɪm."

"Two," Moiraine said. "Three of the seven are broken now. The one I had, and two I found in the High Lord's dwelling in Falme. When all seven are broken, perhaps even before, the patch men put over the hole they drilled into the prison the Creator made will be torn asunder, and the Dark One will once more be able to put his hand through that hole and touch the world. And the only hope of the world is that the Dragon Reborn will be there to face him."

mɪn tʃɹaɪd tə stɑp ɹænd fɹəm θɹoʊɪŋ bæk ðə blæŋkəts, bʌɾ i pʊʃt əɹ dʒɛnli əsaɪd. "aɪ nid tə wɔk." ʃi hɛlpt ɪm ʌp, bʌt wɪð ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni saɪz ən ɡɹʌmbəlz əbaʊɾ ɪm meɪkɪŋ ɪz waʊnd wɝs. hi dɪskʌvɝd ðəɾ ɪz tʃɛst wɑz ɹæpt ɹaʊnd wɪð bændədʒəz. mɪn dʒɹeɪpt wʌn ə ðə blæŋkəts əbaʊɾ ɪz ʃoʊldɝz laɪk ə kloʊk.

Min tried to stop Rand from throwing back the blankets, but he pushed her gently aside. "I need to walk." She helped him up, but with a great many sighs and grumbles about him making his wound worse. He discovered that his chest was wrapped round with bandages. Min draped one of the blankets about his shoulders like a cloak.

fəɹ ə moʊmən i stʊd stɛɹɪŋ daʊn ət ðə hɛɹən-mɑɹk sɔɹd, wʌt wɑz lɛft ʌv ɪt, laɪɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. tæmz sɔɹd. maɪ fɑðɝz sɔɹd. ɹɪlʌktənli, mɔɹ ɹɪlʌktənli ðən i hæɾ ɛvɝ dʌn ɛniθɪŋ ɪn ɪz laɪf, hi lɛt ɡoʊ ʌv ðə hoʊp ðəɾ i wəd dɪskʌvɝ tæm ɹɪli wɑz ɪz fɑðɝ. ɪt fɛlt əz ɪf i wɝ tɛɹɪŋ ɪz hɑɹɾ aʊt. bʌɾ ɪt dɪd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ ðə weɪ hi fɛlt əbaʊt tæm, ən ɛmənz fild wɑz ði oʊnli hoʊm i hæɾ ɛvɝ noʊn. feɪn ɪz ði ɪmpɔɹɾənt θɪŋ. aɪ hæv wʌn duɾi lɛft. stɑpɪŋ hɪm.

For a moment he stood staring down at the heron-mark sword, what was left of it, lying on the ground. Tam's sword. My father's sword. Reluctantly, more reluctantly than he had ever done anything in his life, he let go of the hope that he would discover Tam really was his father. It felt as if he were tearing his heart out. But it did not change the way he felt about Tam, and Emond's Field was the only home he had ever known. Fain is the important thing. I have one duty left. Stopping him.

ðə tu wɪmən hæd tə səpɔɹt hɪm, wʌn ɑn iðɝ ɑɹm, daʊn tə wɛɹ ðə kæmpfaɪɝz wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi bɝnɪŋ, nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm ə ɹoʊɾ ə hɑɹd-pæk dɝt. lɔɪəl wɑz ðɛɹ, ɹiɾɪŋ ə bʊk, tə seɪl bɪɑn ðə sʌnsɛt, ən pɛɹɪn, stɛɹɪŋ ɪndə wʌn ə ðə faɪɝz. ðə ʃaɪnɝənz wɝ meɪkɪŋ pɹɛpɝeɪʃənz fəɹ ðɛɹ ivnɪŋ mil. læn sæɾ ʌndɝ ə tʃɹi ʃɑɹpənɪŋ ɪz bɛl naɪf; ðə wɔɹɾɝ ɡeɪv ɹænd ə kɛɹfəl lʊk, ðən ə nɑd.

The two women had to support him, one on either arm, down to where the campfires were already burning, not far from a road of hard-packed dirt. Loial was there, reading a book, To Sail Beyond the Sunset, and Perrin, staring into one of the fires. The Shienarans were making preparations for their evening meal. Lan sat under a tree sharpening his belt knife; the Warder gave Rand a careful look, then a nod.

ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɛls, tu. ðə dʒɹæɡən bænɝ ɹɪpəld ɑn ðə wɪn oʊvɝ ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə kæmp. sʌmwɛɹ ðeɪ hæd faʊn ə pɹɑpɝ stæf tə ɹipleɪs pɛɹɪnz sæpəlɪŋ.

There was something else, too. The Dragon banner rippled on the wind over the middle of the camp. Somewhere they had found a proper staff to replace Perrin's sapling.

ɹænd dɪmændəd, "wʌɾ ɪz ðət duɪŋ aʊt wɛɹ ɛnibəɾi hu pæsəz baɪ kən si ɪt?"

Rand demanded, "What is that doing out where anybody who passes by can see it?"

"ɪɾ ɪz tu leɪt tə haɪd, ɹænd," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "ɪt wɑz ɔlweɪz tu leɪt fəɹ jə tə haɪd."

"It is too late to hide, Rand," Moiraine said. "It was always too late for you to hide."

"ju doʊn əv tə pʊɾ ʌp ə saɪn seɪɪŋ 'hɪɹ aɪ æm,' iðɝ. əl nɛvɝ faɪn feɪn ɪf sʌmbɑɾi kɪlz mi kəz ə ðət bænɝ." hi tɝn tə lɔɪəl ən pɛɹɪn. "aɪm ɡlæd jə steɪd. aɪ wəɾ əv ʌndɝstʊɾ ɪf jə hædnt."

"You don't have to put up a sign saying 'here I am,' either. I'll never find Fain if somebody kills me because of that banner." He turned to Loial and Perrin. "I'm glad you stayed. I would have understood if you hadn't."

"waɪ wəɾ aɪ nɑt steɪ?" lɔɪəl sɛd. "ju ɑɹ ivən mɔɹ tɑvɝən ðən aɪ bɪlivd, tʃɹu, bʌt jə ɑɹ stɪl maɪ fɹɛnd. aɪ hoʊp jə ɑɹ stɪl maɪ fɹɛnd." hɪz ɪɹz twɪtʃt ənsɝteɪnli.

"Why would I not stay?" Loial said. "You are even more ta'veren than I believed, true, but you are still my friend. I hope you are still my friend." His ears twitched uncertainly.

"aɪ æm," ɹænd sɛd. "fɔɹ əz lɔŋ əz ɪts seɪf fəɹ jə tə bi ɝaʊn mi, ən ivən æftɝ, tu." ði oʊɡiɝz ɡɹɪn nɪɹli splɪɾ ɪz feɪs ɪn tu.

"I am," Rand said. "For as long as it's safe for you to be around me, and even after, too." The Ogier's grin nearly split his face in two.

"aɪm steɪɪŋ əz wɛl," pɛɹɪn sɛd. ðəɹ wɑz ə noʊɾ ə ɹɛzəɡneɪʃən, əɹ æksɛptəns, ɪn ɪz vɔɪs. "ðə wil wivz əs taɪɾ ɪn ðə pæɾɝn, ɹænd. hu wʊɾə θɔɾ ɪt, bæk ɪn ɛmənz fild?"

"I'm staying as well," Perrin said. There was a note of resignation, or acceptance, in his voice. "The Wheel weaves us tight in the Pattern, Rand. Who would have thought it, back in Emond's Field?"

ðə ʃaɪnɝənz wɝ ɡæðɝɪŋ ɝaʊnd. tə ɹændz sɝpɹaɪz, ðeɪ ɔl fɛl tə ðɛɹ niz. ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðɛm wɑtʃt hɪm.

The Shienarans were gathering around. To Rand's surprise, they all fell to their knees. Every one of them watched him.

"wi wəd plɛdʒ aʊɝsɛlvz tə ju," ənoʊ sɛd. ði ʌðɝz nilɪŋ wɪð ɪm nɑɾəd.

"We would pledge ourselves to you," Uno said. The others kneeling with him nodded.

"jɔɹ oʊðz ɑɹ tə ɪŋtʃɹ, ən lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ," ɹænd pɹətɛstəd. "ɪŋtʃɹ daɪd wɛl, ənoʊ. hi daɪd soʊ ðə ɹɛst ʌv əs kəɾ ɪskeɪp wɪð ðə hɔɹn." ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid tə tɛl əm əɹ ɛniwʌn ɛls ðə ɹɛst. hi hoʊp ðəɾ ɪŋtʃɹ hæd faʊn ðə laɪɾ əɡɛn. "tɛl lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ ðət wən jə ɹɪtɝn tə fæl dæɹə."

"Your oaths are to Ingtar, and Lord Agelmar," Rand protested. "Ingtar died well, Uno. He died so the rest of us could escape with the Horn." There was no need to tell them or anyone else the rest. He hoped that Ingtar had found the Light again. "Tell Lord Agelmar that when you return to Fal Dara."

"ɪɾ ɪz sɛd," ðə wʌn-aɪd mæn sɛd kɛɹfəli, "ðæt wən ðə dʒɹæɡən ɪz ɹibɔɹn, hɪl bɹeɪk ɔl oʊðz, ʃæɾɝ ɔl taɪz. nʌθɪŋ hoʊlz ʌs, naʊ. wi wəd ɡɪv əɹ oʊðz tə ju." hi dʒɹu hɪz sɔɹɾ ən leɪɾ ɪt bɪfɔɹ hɪm, hɪl təwɔɹd ɹænd, ən ðə ɹɛst ə ðə ʃaɪnɝənz dɪd ðə seɪm.

"It is said," the one-eyed man said carefully, "that when the Dragon is Reborn, he will break all oaths, shatter all ties. Nothing holds us, now. We would give our oaths to you." He drew his sword and laid it before him, hilt toward Rand, and the rest of the Shienarans did the same.

"ju bæɾəld ðə dɑɹk wʌn," mæsimə sɛd. mæsimə, hu heɪɾəd hɪm. mæsimə, hu lʊkt əɾ ɪm əz ɪf siɪŋ ə vɪʒən ə ðə laɪt. "aɪ sɔ ju, lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən. aɪ sɔ. aɪm jəɹ mæn, tə ðə dɛθ." hɪz dɑɹk aɪz ʃoʊn wɪð fɝvɝ.

"You battled the Dark One," Masema said. Masema, who hated him. Masema, who looked at him as if seeing a vision of the Light. "I saw you, Lord Dragon. I saw. I am your man, to the death." His dark eyes shone with fervor.

"ju mʌs tʃuz, ɹænd," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "ðə wɝld wɪl bi bɹoʊkən wɛðɝ jə bɹeɪk ɪɾ əɹ nɑt. tɑɹmən ɡdən wɪl kʌm, ən ðəɾ əloʊn wɪl tɛɹ ðə wɝld əpɑɹt. wɪl jə stɪl tʃɹaɪ tə haɪd fɹəm wʌt jə ɑɹ, ən liv ðə wɝl tə feɪs ðə læs bæɾəl ʌndɪfɛndəd? tʃuz."

"You must choose, Rand," Moiraine said. "The world will be broken whether you break it or not. Tarmon Gai'don will come, and that alone will tear the world apart. Will you still try to hide from what you are, and leave the world to face the Last Battle undefended? Choose."

ðeɪ wɝ ɔl wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm, ɔl weɪɾɪŋ. dɛθ ɪz laɪɾɝ ðən ə fɛðɝ, duɾi hɛviɝ ðən ə maʊntən. hi meɪɾ ɪz dɪsɪʒən.

They were all watching him, all waiting. Death is lighter than a feather, duty heavier than a mountain. He made his decision.

After

baɪ ʃɪp ən hɔɹs ðə stɔɹiz spɹɛd, baɪ mɝtʃənt wæɡən ən mæn ɑn fʊt, toʊld ən ɹitoʊld, tʃeɪnʒɪŋ jɛɾ ɔlweɪz əlaɪk ət ðə hɑɹt, tə ɑɹæd dumən ən tæɹɑbən ən bɪɑnd, ʌv saɪnz ən pɔɹtɛns ɪn ðə skaɪ əbʌv fɑlm. ən mɛn pɹoʊkleɪm ðɛmsɛlvz fəɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən, ən ʌðɝ mɛn stʃɹʌk əm daʊn ən wɝ stʃɹʌk daʊn ɪn tɝn.

By ship and horse the stories spread, by merchant wagon and man on foot, told and retold, changing yet always alike at the heart, to Arad Doman and Tarabon and beyond, of signs and portents in the sky above Falme. And men proclaimed themselves for the Dragon, and other men struck them down and were struck down in turn.

ʌðɝ teɪlz spɹɛd, ʌv ə kɑləm ðət ɹoʊd fɹəm ðə sɪŋkɪŋ sʌn əkɹɔs ɑlməθ pleɪn. ə hʌnʒɹəd bɔɹɾɝmɪn, ɪt wɑz sɛd. noʊ, ə θaʊzənd. noʊ, ə θaʊzən hɪɹoʊz kʌm bæk fɹəm ðə ɡɹeɪv tə ænsɝ ðə kɔl ə ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ. tɛn θaʊzənd. ðeɪ hæd dɪstʃɹɔɪɾ ə lidʒən ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪɾ ɪntaɪɝ. ðeɪ hæd θɹoʊn ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz ɹɪtɝn ɑɹmiz bæk ɪndə ðə si. ðeɪ wɝ ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz ɑɹmiz ɹɪtɝnd. təwɔɹd ðə maʊntənz ðeɪ ɹoʊd, təwɔɹd ðə dɔn.

Other tales spread, of a column that rode from the sinking sun across Almoth Plain. A hundred Bordermen, it was said. No, a thousand. No, a thousand heroes come back from the grave to answer the call of the Horn of Valere. Ten thousand. They had destroyed a legion of the Children of the Light entire. They had thrown Artur Hawkwing's returned armies back into the sea. They were Artur Hawkwing's armies returned. Toward the mountains they rode, toward the dawn.

jɛt wʌn θɪŋ ɛvɹi teɪl hæd ðə seɪm. ət ðɛɹ hɛd ɹoʊɾ ə mæn huz feɪs hæd bɪn sin ɪn ðə skaɪ əbʌv fɑlm, ən ðeɪ ɹoʊɾ ʌndɝ ðə bænɝ ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn.

Yet one thing every tale had the same. At their head rode a man whose face had been seen in the sky above Falme, and they rode under the banner of the Dragon Reborn.

ən mɛn kɹaɪɾ aʊt tə ðə kɹieɪɾɝ, seɪɪŋ, oʊ laɪɾ ə ðə hɛvənz, laɪɾ ə ðə wɝld, lɛt ðə pɹɑməst wʌn bi bɔɹn ə ðə maʊntən, əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ðə pɹɑfəsiz, əz i wɑz ɪn eɪdʒəz pæst ən wɪl bi ɪn eɪdʒəz tə kʌm. lɛt ðə pɹɪns ə ðə mɔɹnɪŋ sɪŋ tə ðə læn ðət ɡɹin θɪŋz wɪl ɡɹoʊ ən ðə væliz ɡɪv fɔɹθ læmz. lɛt ði ɑɹm ə ðə lɔɹɾ ə ðə dɔn ʃɛltɝ əs fɹəm ðə dɑɹk, ən ðə ɡɹeɪt sɔɹɾ ə dʒʌstəs dɪfɛn ʌs. lɛt ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹaɪɾ əɡɛn ɑn ðə wɪnz ə taɪm.

And men cried out to the Creator, saying, O Light of the Heavens, Light of the World, let the Promised One be born of the mountain, according to the Prophecies, as he was in Ages past and will be in Ages to come. Let the Prince of the Morning sing to the land that green things will grow and the valleys give forth lambs. Let the arm of the Lord of the Dawn shelter us from the Dark, and the great sword of justice defend us. Let the Dragon ride again on the winds of time.

 - fɹəm tʃɹəl dʒɹiənɑn ti kələmən, ðə saɪkəl ə ðə dʒɹæɡən, ɔθɝ ənnoʊn, ðə fɔɹθ eɪdʒ ði ɛn ə ðə sɛkən bʊk ə ðə wil ə taɪm ɡlɔsɝi eɪ noʊɾ ɑn deɪts ɪn ðɪs ɡlɔsɝi. θɹi sɪstəmz ə ɹəkɔɹɾɪŋ deɪts əv bɪn ɪn dʒɛnɝəl jus sɪns ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld. ðə fɝst ɹəkɔɹɾəd jɪɹz æftɝ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ (æb). sɪns ðə jɪɹz ə ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ən ɪmiɾiətli æftɝ wɝ jɪɹz ʌv ɔlmoʊs toʊɾəl keɪɑs, ən sɪns ðɪs kæləndɝ wɑz ədɑptəɾ ə ɡʊd hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz æftɝ ði ɛn ə ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ, ɪts stɑɹɾɪŋ pɔɪnt wɑz ɑɹbɪtʃɹɛɹəli əsaɪnd. ət ði ɛn ə ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz mɛni ɹɛkɝdz hæd bɪn lɔst, soʊ mʌtʃ soʊ ðət ðəɹ wɑz ɑɹɡjəmən əbaʊt ði ɪɡzæk jɪɹ ʌndɝ ði oʊl sɪstəm. ə nu kæləndɝ wɑz ðɛɹfɔɹ ɪstæblɪʃt, deɪɾɪŋ fɹəm ði ɛn ə ðə wɔɹz ən sɛləbɹeɪɾɪŋ ðə səpoʊz fɹiɾəm ə ðə wɝl fɹəm ðə tʃɹɑlɑk θɹɛt. ðɪs sɛkən kæləndɝ ɹəkɔɹɾəd itʃ jɪɹ əz fɹi jɪɹ (fi). æftɝ ðə dɪsɹʌpʃən, dɛθ, ən dɪstʃɹʌkʃən kɑz baɪ ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz, ə θɝd kæləndɝ keɪm ɪndə biɪŋ. ðɪs kæləndɝ, ʌv ðə nu ɛɹə (nəbɹæskə), ɪz kɝənli ɪn jus.

 - from Charal Drianaan te Calamon, The Cycle of the Dragon, Author unknown, the Fourth Age The End of the Second Book of The Wheel of Time GLOSSARY A Note on Dates in This Glossary. Three systems of recording dates have been in general use since the Breaking of the World. The first recorded years After the Breaking (AB). Since the years of the Breaking and immediately after were years of almost total chaos, and since this calendar was adopted a good hundred years after the end of the Breaking, its starting point was arbitrarily assigned. At the end of the Trolloc Wars many records had been lost, so much so that there was argument about the exact year under the old system. A new calendar was therefore established, dating from the end of the Wars and celebrating the supposed freedom of the world from the Trolloc threat. This second calendar recorded each year as Free Year (FY). After the disruption, death, and destruction caused by the War of the Hundred Years, a third calendar came into being. This calendar, of the New Era (NE), is currently in use.

æɾəm (aɪ-dæm): ə dɪvaɪs, kənsɪstɪŋ ʌv ə kɑlɝ ən ə bɹeɪslət lɪŋk baɪ ə sɪlvɝi mɛɾəl liʃ, ðət meɪ bi juz tə kəntʃɹoʊl, əɡɛnst əɹ wɪl, ɛni wʊmən u kən tʃænəl. ðə kɑlɝ ɪz wɔɹn baɪ ðə deɪmeɪn, ðə bɹeɪslət baɪ ðə sʌldəm. si ɔlsoʊ deɪmeɪn; sʌldəm.

a'dam (AYE-dam): A device, consisting of a collar and a bracelet linked by a silvery metal leash, that may be used to control, against her will, any woman who can channel. The collar is worn by the damane, the bracelet by the sul'dam. See also damane; sul'dam.

ɛɛs sədaɪ (aɪɛz sɛ-dɪaɪ): wildɝz ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ. sɪns ðə taɪm ə mædnəs, ɔl sɝvaɪvɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑɹ wɪmən. waɪdli dɪstʃɹʌstəɾ ən fɪɹd, ivən heɪɾəd, ðeɪ ɑɹ bleɪm baɪ mɛni fəɹ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld, ən ɑɹ θɔt tə mɛɾəl ɪn ði əfɛɹz ə neɪʃənz. ət ðə seɪm taɪm, fju ɹulɝz wɪl bi wɪθaʊɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ædvaɪzɝ, ivən ɪn lænz wɛɹ ði ɛɡzɪstəns ə sətʃ ə kənɛkʃən mʌs bi kɛp sikɹət. si ɔlsoʊ ədʒɑ; æmɪɝlɪn sit; taɪm ə mædnəs.

Aes Sedai (EYEZ seh-DEYE): Wielders of the One Power. Since the Time of Madness, all surviving Aes Sedai are women. Widely distrusted and feared, even hated, they are blamed by many for the Breaking of the World, and are thought to meddle in the affairs of nations. At the same time, few rulers will be without an Aes Sedai advisor, even in lands where the existence of such a connection must be kept secret. See also Ajah; Amyrlin Seat; Time of Madness.

eɪɡəlmɝ; lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ ə haʊs dʒəɡəd (æɡ-ɛl-mɑɹ; dʒɑ-ɡæd): lɔɹɾ ə fæl dæɹə. hɪz saɪn ɪz θɹi ɹʌnɪŋ ɹɛd fɑksəz.

Agelmar; Lord Agelmar of House Jagad (AGH-el-mar; JAH-gad): Lord of Fal Dara. His sign is three running red foxes.

eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz: ði eɪdʒ ɛndəd baɪ ðə wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ ən ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld. ə taɪm wən ɛɛs sədaɪ pɝfɔɹmd wʌndɝz naʊ oʊnli dʒɹimd ʌv. si ɔlsoʊ wil ə taɪm; bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld; wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ.

Age of Legends: The Age ended by the War of the Shadow and the Breaking of the World. A time when Aes Sedai performed wonders now only dreamed of. See also Wheel of Time; Breaking of the World; War of the Shadow.

il (aɪ-il): ðə pipəl ə ði il weɪst. fɪɹs ən hɑɹɾi. ɔlsoʊ kɔld ilmɛn. ðeɪ veɪl ðɛɹ feɪsəz bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ kɪl, ɡɪvɪŋ ɹaɪz tə ðə seɪɪŋ "æktɪŋ laɪk ə blæk-veɪld il" tə dɪskɹaɪb sʌmwʌn u ɪz biɪŋ vaɪələnt. dɛdli wɔɹiɝz wɪð wɛpənz əɹ wɪð nʌθɪŋ bʌt ðɛɹ bɛɹ hænz, ðəl nɑt tʌtʃ ə sɔɹd. ðɛɹ paɪpɝz pleɪ ðɛm ɪndə bæɾəl wɪð ðə mjuzɪk ə dænsəz, ən ilmɛn kɔl bæɾəl "ðə dæns." si ɔlsoʊ il wɔɹiɝ səsaɪəɾiz; il weɪst.

Aiel (eye-EEL): The people of the Aiel Waste. Fierce and hardy. Also called Aielmen. They veil their faces before they kill, giving rise to the saying "acting like a black-veiled Aiel" to describe someone who is being violent. Deadly warriors with weapons or with nothing but their bare hands, they will not touch a sword. Their pipers play them into battle with the music of dances, and Aielmen call battle "the Dance." See also Aiel warrior societies; Aiel Waste.

il wɔɹiɝ səsaɪəɾiz: il wɔɹiɝz ɑɹ ɔl mɛmbɝz ʌv wʌn ə ðə wɔɹiɝ səsaɪəɾiz, sətʃ əz ðə stoʊn dɑɡz, ðə ɹɛd ʃilz, əɹ ðə meɪɾənz ə ðə spɪɹ. itʃ səsaɪəɾi hæz ɪts oʊn kʌstəmz, ən səmtaɪmz spəsɪfɪk duɾiz. fəɹ ɪɡzæmpəl, ɹɛd ʃilz ækt əz pəlis. stoʊn dɑɡz ɔfən vaʊ nɑt tə ɹitʃɹit wʌns bæɾəl əz bɪn dʒɔɪnd, ən wɪl daɪ tə ðə læs mæn ɪf nɛsəsɛɹi tə fʊlfɪl ðɪs vaʊ. ðə klænz ə ði il fɹikwənli faɪɾ əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz, bʌt mɛmbɝz ə ðə seɪm səsaɪəɾi wɪl nɑt faɪt wʌn ənʌðɝ ivən ɪf ðɛɹ klænz ɑɹ duɪŋ soʊ. ɪn ðɪs weɪ, ðəɹ ɑɹ ɔlweɪz laɪnz ə kɑntæk bɪtwin ðə klænz ivən wən ðeɪ ɑɹ ɪn oʊpən wɔɹfɛɹ. si ɔlsoʊ il; il weɪst; fɑɹ dɛɹiz maɪ.

Aiel warrior societies: Aiel warriors are all members of one of the warrior societies, such as the Stone Dogs, the Red Shields, or the Maidens of the Spear. Each society has its own customs, and sometimes specific duties. For example, Red Shields act as police. Stone Dogs often vow not to retreat once battle has been joined, and will die to the last man if necessary to fulfill this vow. The clans of the Aiel frequently fight among themselves, but members of the same society will not fight one another even if their clans are doing so. In this way, there are always lines of contact between the clans even when they are in open warfare. See also Aiel; Aiel Waste; Far Dareis Mai.

il weɪst: ðə hɑɹʃ, ɹʌɡəd, ən ɔl-bʌt-wɔɾɝləs læn ist ə ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝld. fju aʊtsaɪɾɝz vɛntʃɝ ðɛɹ, nɑɾ oʊnli kəz wɔɾɝ ɪz ɔlmoʊst ɪmpɑsəbəl tə faɪn fəɹ wʌn nɑt bɔɹn ðɛɹ, bʌt kəz ði il kənsɪɾɝ ðɛmsɛlvz ət wɔɹ wɪð ɔl ʌðɝ pipəlz ən də nɑt wɛlkəm stʃɹeɪnʒɝz.

Aiel Waste: The harsh, rugged, and all-but-waterless land east of the Spine of the World. Few outsiders venture there, not only because water is almost impossible to find for one not born there, but because the Aiel consider themselves at war with all other peoples and do not welcome strangers.

ədʒɑ (ɑ-dʒɑ): səsaɪəɾiz əmʌŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tə wɪtʃ ɔl ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪksɛp ði æmɪɝlɪn sit bɪlɔŋ. ðeɪ ɑɹ dɛzɪɡneɪɾɪd baɪ kʌlɝz: blu, ɹɛd, waɪt, ɡɹin, bɹaʊn, jɛloʊ, ən ɡɹeɪ. itʃ fɑloʊz ə spəsɪfɪk fəlɑsəfi ʌv ðə jus ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ ən ðə pɝpəsəz ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. fəɹ ɪɡzæmpəl, ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ bɛnz ɔl ɪts ɛnɝdʒiz tə faɪndɪŋ mɛn u ɑɹ ətɛmptɪŋ tə wil ðə paʊɝ ən tə dʒɛntəlɪŋ ðɛm. ðə bɹaʊn ədʒɑ, ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, fɔɹseɪks ɪnvɑlvmənt wɪð ðə məndeɪn wɝld ən dɛɾɪkeɪts ɪtsɛlf tə sikɪŋ nɑlədʒ. ðəɹ ɑɹ ɹumɝz (hɑtli dɪnaɪd, ən nɛvɝ seɪfli mɛnʃən ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ) ʌv ə blæk ədʒɑ, dɛɾəkeɪtəd tə sɝvɪŋ ðə dɑɹk wʌn.

Ajah (AH-jah): Societies among the Aes Sedai to which all Aes Sedai except the Amyrlin Seat belong. They are designated by colors: Blue, Red, White, Green, Brown, Yellow, and Gray. Each follows a specific philosophy of the use of the One Power and the purposes of the Aes Sedai. For example, the Red Ajah bends all its energies to finding men who are attempting to wield the Power and to gentling them. The Brown Ajah, on the other hand, forsakes involvement with the mundane world and dedicates itself to seeking knowledge. There are rumors (hotly denied, and never safely mentioned in front of any Aes Sedai) of a Black Ajah, dedicated to serving the Dark One.

ɑlɑnə mɑsvɑni (ɑ-læn-nɑ mɔs-væn-ni): ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌv ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ.

Alanna Mosvani (ah-LAN-nah mos-VANH-nie): An Aes Sedai of the Green Ajah.

ælɑntɪn (ɑ-læn-tɪn): ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "bɹʌðɝ;" ʃɔɹt fəɹ tiə ɑvɛn ælɑntɪn, "bɹʌðɝ tə ðə tʃɹiz;" "tʃɹibɹəðɝ."

alantin (ah-LANH-tin): In the Old Tongue, "Brother;" short for tia avende alantin, "Brother to the Trees;" "Treebrother."

eɪlɑɹ (aɪ-lɑɹ): ɛldəst ə ði ɛldɝz ə stɛɾɪŋ tsəfu.

Alar (AYE-lahr): Eldest of the Elders of Stedding Tsofu.

ɑldib (ɑl-dib): ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "wɛst waɪnd," ðə wɪn ðət bɹɪŋz ðə spɹɪŋ ɹeɪnz.

Aldieb (ahl-DEEB): In the Old Tongue, "West Wind," the wind that brings the spring rains.

ɑlmɹə, nɪneɪiv (ɑl-miɝ-ɑ, naɪ-niv): ə wʊmən fɹəm ɛmənz fild, ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz dɪstʃɹɪkt ʌv ændɝ (æn-dɔɹ).

al'Meara, Nynaeve (ahl-MEER-ah, NIGH-neev): A woman from Emond's Field, in the Two Rivers district of Andor (AN-door).

ælθɹ, ɹænd (ɑl-θɔɹ, ɹænd): ə jʌŋ mæn fɹəm ɛmənz fild, wʌns ə ʃɛpɝd.

al'Thor, Rand (ahl-THOR, RAND): A young man from Emond's Field, once a shepherd.

ælvɪɹ, ɛɡwin (ɑl-vɪɹ, ɛ-ɡweɪn): ə jʌŋ wʊmən fɹəm ɛmənz fild.

al'Vere, Egwene (ahl-VEER, eh-GWAIN): A young woman from Emond's Field.

əmælisə, leɪɾi (ɑ-mɑ-li-sɑ): ʃaɪnɝən ə haʊs dʒəɡəd; lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝz sɪstɝ.

Amalisa, Lady (ah-mah-LEE-sah): Shienaran of House Jagad; Lord Agelmar's sister.

æmɪɝlɪn sit (ɑm-ɛɹ-lɪn sit): (wʌn) ðə taɪɾəl ə ðə liɾɝ ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɪlɛktəd fəɹ laɪf baɪ ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ, ðə haɪəs kaʊnsəl ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, wɪtʃ kənsɪsts ə θɹi ɹɛpɹəzɛntəɾɪvz (kɔl sɪɾɝz) fɹəm itʃ ə ðə sɛvən ədʒəz. ði æmɪɝlɪn sit hæz, θiɝɛɾɪkəli ət list, ɔlmoʊst səpɹim əθɔɹəɾi əmʌŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən ɹæŋks soʊʃəli əz ði ikwəl ʌv ə kɪŋ əɹ kwin. ə slaɪtli lɛs fɔɹməl jusədʒ ɪz sɪmpli ði æmɪɝlɪn. (tu) ðə θɹoʊn əpɑn wɪtʃ ðə liɾɝ ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sɪts.

Amyrlin Seat (AHM-ehr-lin SEAT): (1) The title of the leader of the Aes Sedai. Elected for life by the Hall of the Tower, the highest council of the Aes Sedai, which consists of three representatives (called Sitters) from each of the seven Ajahs. The Amyrlin Seat has, theoretically at least, almost supreme authority among the Aes Sedai, and ranks socially as the equal of a king or queen. A slightly less formal usage is simply the Amyrlin. (2) The throne upon which the leader of the Aes Sedai sits.

æneɪjə (ɑ-naɪ-jɑ): ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌv ðə blu ədʒɑ.

Anaiya (ah-NYE-yah): An Aes Sedai of the Blue Ajah.

æŋɡɹil (æn-ɡɹi-ɑl): ə vɛɹi ɹɛɹ əbdʒɛk ðəɾ əlaʊz ɛniwʌn keɪpəbəl ə tʃænəlɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ tə hændəl ə ɡɹeɪɾɝ əmaʊn ə ðə paʊɝ ðən wəd bi seɪfli pɑsəbəl əneɪɾɪd. ɹɛmnəns ə ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz, ðə minz ə ðɛɹ meɪkɪŋ ɪz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ noʊn. fju ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ɛɡzɪstəns. si ɔlsoʊ sɑŋɡɹil; tɛɹæŋɡɹil.

angreal (anh-gree-AHL): A very rare object that allows anyone capable of channeling the One Power to handle a greater amount of the Power than would be safely possible unaided. Remnants of the Age of Legends, the means of their making is no longer known. Few remain in existence. See also sa'angreal; ter'angreal.

ɑɹæd dumən (ɑ-ɹɑd du-mæn): ə neɪʃən ɑn ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən.

Arad Doman (AH-rahd do-MAHN): A nation on the Aryth Ocean.

ɝæfəl (ɑ-ɹɑ-fɛl): wʌn ə ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz.

Arafel (AH-rah-fehl): One of the Borderlands.

ɑvɛndɪsɔɹə (ɑ-vɛn-dɛ-soʊ-ɹɑ): ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "ðə tʃɹi ʌv laɪf." mɛnʃən ɪn mɛni stɔɹiz ən lɛdʒənz.

Avendesora (AH-vehn-deh-SO-rah): In the Old Tongue, "the Tree of Life." Mentioned in many stories and legends.

eɪbɑɹə, pɛɹɪn (eɪ-bɛɹ-ɑ, pɛɹ-ɹɪn): ə jʌŋ mæn fɹəm ɛmənz fild, fɔɹmɝli ə blæksmɪθs əpɹɛntəs.

Aybara, Perrin (ay-BAHR-ah, PEHR-rihn): A young man from Emond's Field, formerly a blacksmith's apprentice.

bælzəmən (bɑ-ɑl-zɑ-moʊn): ɪn ðə tʃɹɑlɑk tʌŋ, "hɑɹɾ ə ðə dɑɹk." bɪliv tə bi ðə tʃɹɑlɑk neɪm fəɹ ðə dɑɹk wʌn. si ɔlsoʊ dɑɹk wʌn; tʃɹɑləks.

Ba'alzamon (bah-AHL-zah-mon): In the Trolloc tongue, "Heart of the Dark." Believed to be the Trolloc name for the Dark One. See also Dark One; Trollocs.

bɑɹθeɪnz, lɔɹd, ʌv haʊs dəmədʒɹd (bɛɹ-ðæn-nɛs): kɛɹhinɪn lɔɹd, sɛkən oʊnli tə ðə kɪŋ ɪn paʊɝ. hɪz pɝsənəl saɪn ɪz ðə tʃɑɹdʒɪŋ bɔɹ. ðə saɪn ə haʊs dəmədʒɹɾ ɪz ðə kɹaʊn ən tʃɹi.

Barthanes, Lord, of House Damodred (bahr-THAN-nehs): Cairhienin lord, second only to the king in power. His personal sign is the Charging Boar. The sign of House Damodred is the Crown and Tree.

bɛl taɪn (bɛl taɪn): spɹɪŋ fɛstəvəl sɛləbɹeɪɾɪŋ ði ɛn ʌv wɪntɝ, ðə fɝst spɹaʊɾɪŋ ə kɹɑps, ən ðə bɝθ ə ðə fɝs læmz.

Bel Tine (BEHL TINE): Spring festival celebrating the end of winter, the first sprouting of crops, and the birth of the first lambs.

bɪtʃɹeɪɝ ə hoʊp: si ɪʃəml.

Betrayer of Hope: See Ishamael.

bɝdʒɪt (bɝ-dʒit-tɛ): ɡoʊldən-hɛɹd hɛɹoʊən ə lɛdʒən ən ə hʌnʒɹəd ɡlimənz teɪlz, ʃi hæɾ ə sɪlvɝ baʊ ən sɪlvɝ æɹoʊz, wɪð wɪtʃ ʃi nɛvɝ mɪst.

Birgitte (ber-GEET-teh): Golden-haired heroine of legend and a hundred gleemen's tales, she had a silver bow and silver arrows, with which she never missed.

bɪɾɝn (-tɛɹn): ə mjuzɪkəl ɪnstʃɹəmən ðət meɪ hæv sɪks, naɪn, əɹ twɛlv stʃɹɪŋz, ən ɪz hɛl flæɾ ɑn ðə niz ən pleɪd baɪ plʌkɪŋ əɹ stʃɹʌmɪŋ.

bittern (BIHT-tehrn): A musical instrument that may have six, nine, or twelve strings, and is held flat on the knees and played by plucking or strumming.

blæstəd lænz: dɛsəleɪɾɪd lænz sɝaʊndɪŋ ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl, bɪɑn ðə ɡɹeɪt blaɪt.

Blasted Lands: Desolated lands surrounding Shayol Ghul, beyond the Great Blight.

blaɪt, ðə: si ɡɹeɪt blaɪt, ðə.

Blight, the: See Great Blight, the.

bɔɹɾɝlændz, ðə: ðə neɪʃənz bɔɹɾɝɪŋ ðə ɡɹeɪt blaɪt. sɑldɑiə, ɝæfəl, kændɝ, ən ʃaɪnɝ.

Borderlands, the: The nations bordering the Great Blight. Saldaea, Arafel, Kandor, and Shienar.

bɔɹnhəld, dʒɛəfɹæm (-hɑld, -ɹæm): eɪ lɔɹd kæptən ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt.

Bornhald, Geofram (BOHRN-hahld, JEHF-rahm): A Lord Captain of the Children of the Light.

bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld, ðə: dʊɹɪŋ ðə taɪm ə mædnəs, meɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ hu hæd ɡɔn ɪnseɪn, ən u kəd wil ðə wʌn paʊɝ tə ə dɪɡɹi naʊ ənnoʊn, tʃeɪnʒd ðə feɪs ə ði ɝθ. ðeɪ kɑzd ɡɹeɪɾ ɝθkweɪks, lɛvəld oʊl maʊntən ɹeɪnʒəz ən ɹeɪz nu maʊntənz, lɪftəd dʒɹaɪ lænd wɛɹ siz hæd bɪn ən meɪd ði oʊʃən ɹʌʃ ɪn wɛɹ dʒɹaɪ læn hæd bɪn. mɛni pɑɹts ə ðə wɝld wɝ kəmplitli dɪpɑpjəleɪɾɪd, ən ðə sɝvaɪvɝz wɝ skæɾɝd laɪk dʌst ɑn ðə wɪnd. ðɪs dɪstʃɹʌkʃən ɪz ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ɪn stɔɹiz, lɛdʒənz, ən hɪstɝi əz ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld. si ɔlsoʊ taɪm ə mædnəs.

Breaking of the World, the: During the Time of Madness, male Aes Sedai who had gone insane, and who could wield the One Power to a degree now unknown, changed the face of the earth. They caused great earthquakes, leveled old mountain ranges and raised new mountains, lifted dry land where seas had been and made the ocean rush in where dry land had been. Many parts of the world were completely depopulated, and the survivors were scattered like dust on the wind. This destruction is remembered in stories, legends, and history as the Breaking of the World. See also Time of Madness.

baɪɑɝ, jɹət (baɪ-ɑɹ, dʒɑ-ɹɛt): ən ɔfəsɝ ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt.

Byar, Jaret (BY-ahr, JAH-ret): An officer of the Children of the Light.

keɪɛmlɪn (keɪm-lɪn): ðə kæpəɾəl sɪɾi ʌv ændɝ.

Caemlyn (KAYM-lihn): The capital city of Andor.

kɛɹhin (kaɪ-ɹi-ɛn): boʊθ ə neɪʃən əlɔŋ ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝld ən ðə kæpəɾəl sɪɾi ʌv ðət neɪʃən. ðə sɪɾi wɑz bɝn ən luɾəd dʊɹɪŋ ði il wɔɹ (naɪnsɛvənsɪksnaɪnsɛvəneɪt ni). ðə saɪn ə kɛɹhin ɪz ə mɛni-ɹeɪd ɡoʊldən sʌn ɹaɪzɪŋ fɹəm ðə bɑɾəm ʌv ə fild ə skaɪ blu.

Cairhien (KEYE-ree-EHN): Both a nation along the Spine of the World and the capital city of that nation. The city was burned and looted during the Aiel War (976978 NE). The sign of Cairhien is a many-rayed golden sun rising from the bottom of a field of sky blue.

kæɹələn (kɑ-ɹɑ-leɪn): wʌn ə ðə neɪʃənz ɹʌŋ fɹəm ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz ɛmpaɪɝ dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz. ɪt wikən ðɛɹæftɝ, ən ðə læs tʃɹeɪsəz vænɪʃt əbaʊt faɪvhʌnʒɹəd ni.

Caralain (KAH-rah-layn): One of the nations wrung from Artur Hawkwing's empire during the War of the Hundred Years. It weakened thereafter, and the last traces vanished about 500 NE.

kɔθən, mæt (kɔ-θɑn, mæt): ə jʌŋ mæn fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. fʊl neɪm: meɪtʃɹim (mæt-ɹɪm) kɔθən.

Cauthon, Mat (CAW-thon, MAT): A young man from the Two Rivers. Full name: Matrim (MAT-rihm) Cauthon.

tʃænəl: (vɝb) tə kəntʃɹoʊl ðə floʊ ʌv ðə wʌn paʊɝ. si ɔlsoʊ wʌn paʊɝ.

channel: (verb) To control the flow of the One Power. See also One Power.

tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt: ə səsaɪəɾi hoʊldɪŋ stʃɹɪkt əsɛɾɪk bɪlifs, dɛɾəkeɪtəd tə ðə dɪfiɾ ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn ən ðə dɪstʃɹʌkʃən ʌv ɔl dɑɹkfɹɛnz. faʊndəd dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz baɪ lɑthɛɹ mæntəlɝ (loʊ-θheɪɹ mæn-ti-lɑɹ) tə pɹɑsələtaɪz əɡɛns ði ɪnkɹisɪŋ nʌmbɝz ə dɑɹkfɹɛnz, ðeɪ ɪvɑlv dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ɪndə ə kəmplitli mɪlətɛɹi ɔɹɡənəzeɪʃən, ɪkstʃɹimli ɹɪdʒəɾ ɪn ðɛɹ bɪlifs, ən kəmplitli sɝɾən ðəɾ oʊnli ðeɪ noʊ ðə tʃɹuθ ən ðə ɹaɪt. ðeɪ heɪɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ðɛm, ən ɛni hu səpɔɹɾ əɹ bɪfɹɛn ðɛm, dɑɹkfɹɛnz. ðeɪ ɑɹ noʊn dɪspɛɹɪdʒɪŋli əz waɪtkloʊks. ðɛɹ saɪn ɪz ə ɡoʊldən sʌnbɝst ɑn ə fild ʌv waɪt.

Children of the Light: A society holding strict ascetic beliefs, dedicated to the defeat of the Dark One and the destruction of all Darkfriends. Founded during the War of the Hundred Years by Lothair Mantelar (LOH-thayr MAHN-tee-LAHR) to proselytize against the increasing numbers of Darkfriends, they evolved during the war into a completely military organization, extremely rigid in their beliefs, and completely certain that only they know the truth and the right. They hate Aes Sedai, considering them, and any who support or befriend them, Darkfriends. They are known disparagingly as Whitecloaks. Their sign is a golden sunburst on a field of white.

kɹɑnəkəlz, kipɝ ə ðə: sɛkən ɪn əθɔɹəɾi tə ði æmɪɝlɪn siɾ əmʌŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ʃi ɔlsoʊ æks əz sɛkɹətɛɹi tə ði æmɪɝlɪn. tʃoʊzən fəɹ laɪf baɪ ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ, ən juʒəwəli ʌv ðə seɪm ədʒɑ əz ði æmɪɝlɪn. si ɔlsoʊ æmɪɝlɪn sit; ədʒɑ.

Chronicles, Keeper of the: Second in authority to the Amyrlin Seat among the Aes Sedai, she also acts as secretary to the Amyrlin. Chosen for life by the Hall of the Tower, and usually of the same Ajah as the Amyrlin. See also Amyrlin Seat; Ajah.

kɔɝɪn (koʊ-ɹin-nɛ): ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "ɹɪtɝn," əɹ "ðə ɹɪtɝn."

Corenne (koh-REEN-neh): In the Old Tongue, "Return," or "the Return."

kʌvənən ə ðə tɛn neɪʃənz: ə junjən fɔɹmd ɪn ðə sɛntʃɝiz æftɝ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld wən neɪʃənz wɝ fɝst ɹɛkɹieɪɾɪd (sɝkə θɹihʌnʒɹəd æb). dɛɾəkeɪtəd tə ðə dɪfiɾ ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn. bɹoʊkən əpɑɹt baɪ ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz. si ɔlsoʊ tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz.

Covenant of the Ten Nations: A union formed in the centuries after the Breaking of the World when nations were first recreated (circa 300 AB). Dedicated to the defeat of the Dark One. Broken apart by the Trolloc Wars. See also Trolloc Wars.

kwəndɪlɝ (kweɪn-dɝ-jɑɹ): ɔlsoʊ noʊn əz hɑɹtstoʊn. si hɑɹtstoʊn.

cuendillar (CWAIN-der-yar): Also known as heartstone. See heartstone.

deɪz deɪmɑɹ (dɑ-ɛs deɪ-mɑɹ): ðə ɡɹeɪt ɡeɪm, ɔlsoʊ noʊn əz ðə ɡeɪm ə haʊsəz. neɪm ɡɪvən ðə skimɪŋ, plɑts, ən mənɪpjəleɪʃənz fəɹ ædvæntɪdʒ baɪ ðə noʊbəl haʊsəz. ɡɹeɪt vælju ɪz ɡɪvən tə sʌɾəlti, tə eɪmɪŋ ət wʌn θɪŋ waɪl simɪŋ tə eɪm əɾ ənʌðɝ, ən tə ətʃivɪŋ ɛnz wɪð ðə lis vɪzəbəl ɛfɝt.

Daes Dae'mar (DAH-ess day-MAR): The Great Game, also known as the Game of Houses. Name given the scheming, plots, and manipulations for advantage by the noble Houses. Great value is given to subtlety, to aiming at one thing while seeming to aim at another, and to achieving ends with the least visible effort.

daɪ ʃæn (daɪ ʃæn): ə taɪɾəl ɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz minɪŋ daɪəɾɪmd bæɾəl lɔɹd. si ɔlsoʊ bɔɹɾɝlændz.

Dai Shan (DYE SHAN): A title in the Borderlands meaning Diademed Battle Lord. See also Borderlands.

deɪmeɪn (dɑ-mæn-i): ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "liʃt wʌnz." wɪmən u kən tʃænəl u ɑɹ hɛl pɹɪznɝ baɪ æɾəm ən juz baɪ ðə sintʃæn fəɹ mɛni pɝpəsəz, tʃifɛst ə ðiz biɪŋ əz wɛpənz ɪn bæɾəl. si ɔlsoʊ sintʃæn; æɾəm; sʌldəm.

damane (dah-MAHN-ee): In the Old Tongue, "Leashed Ones." Women who can channel who are held prisoner by a'dam and used by the Seanchan for many purposes, chiefest of these being as weapons in battle. See also Seanchan; a'dam; sul'dam.

dəmədʒɹd, lɔɹd ɡɑleɪdɛdʒɹəd (dæm-oʊ-dʒɹɛd, ɡɑ-lɑd-ɛ-dʒɹaɪd): hæf-bɹʌðɝ tə ɪleɪn ən ɡɔɪn. hɪz saɪn ɪz ə wɪŋ sɪlvɝ sɔɹd, pɔɪn daʊn.

Damodred, Lord Galadedrid (DAHM-oh-drehd, gah-LAHD-eh-drihd): Half-brother to Elayne and Gawyn. His sign is a winged silver sword, point down.

dɑɹkfɹɛnz: ðoʊz u fɑloʊ ðə dɑɹk wʌn ən bɪliv ðəl ɡeɪn ɡɹeɪt paʊɝ ən ɹɪwɔɹdz, ən ivən ɪmɔɹtælɪɾi, wən hiz fɹid fɹəm ɪz pɹɪzən.

Darkfriends: Those who follow the Dark One and believe they will gain great power and rewards, and even immortality, when he is freed from his prison.

dɑɹk wʌn: moʊs kɑmən neɪm, juzd ɪn ɛvɹi lænd, fəɹ ʃeɪtɑn. ðə sɔɹs ʌv ivəl, æntɪθəsəs ə ðə kɹieɪɾɝ. ɪmpɹɪzən baɪ ðə kɹieɪɾɝ ət ðə moʊmən ə kɹieɪʃən ɪn ə pɹɪzən ət ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl. ən ətɛmp tə fɹi hɪm fɹəm ðət pɹɪzən bɹɔɾ əbaʊt ðə wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ, ðə teɪntɪŋ ə seɪɾɪn, ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld, ən ði ɛn ə ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz.

Dark One: Most common name, used in every land, for Shai'tan. The source of evil, antithesis of the Creator. Imprisoned by the Creator at the moment of Creation in a prison at Shayol Ghul. An attempt to free him from that prison brought about the War of the Shadow, the tainting of saidin, the Breaking of the World, and the end of the Age of Legends.

dɑɹk wʌn, neɪmɪŋ ðə: seɪɪŋ ðə tʃɹu neɪm ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn (ʃeɪtɑn) dʒɹɔz ɪz ətɛnʃən, ɪnɛvəɾəbli bɹɪŋɪŋ ɪl fɔɹtʃən ət bɛst, dɪzæstɝ ət wɝst. fəɹ ðət ɹizən, mɛni jufəmɪzəmz ɑɹ juzd, əmʌŋ əm ðə dɑɹk wʌn, fɑðɝ ə laɪz, saɪtblɪndɝ, lɔɹɾ ə ðə ɡɹeɪv, ʃɛpɝɾ ə ðə naɪt, hɑɹtsbeɪn, hɑɹtfæŋ, ɡɹæsbɝnɝ, ən lifblaɪɾɝ. sʌmwʌn u simz tə bi ɪnvaɪɾɪŋ ɪl fɔɹtʃən ɪz ɔfən sɛd tə bi "neɪmɪŋ ðə dɑɹk wʌn."

Dark One, naming the: Saying the true name of the Dark One (Shai'tan) draws his attention, inevitably bringing ill fortune at best, disaster at worst. For that reason, many euphemisms are used, among them the Dark One, Father of Lies, Sightblinder, Lord of the Grave, Shepherd of the Night, Heartsbane, Heartfang, Grassburner, and Leafblighter. Someone who seems to be inviting ill fortune is often said to be "naming the Dark One."

dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ: taɪɾəl ə ði ɛɹ tə ðə θɹoʊn ʌv ændɝ. ði ɛldəs dɔɾɝ ə ðə kwin səksidz əɹ mʌðɝ ɑn ðə θɹoʊn. wɪθaʊɾ ə sɝvaɪvɪŋ dɔɾɝ, ðə θɹoʊn ɡoʊz tə ðə nɪɹəs fimeɪl blʌd ɹileɪʃən ə ðə kwin.

Daughter-Heir: Title of the heir to the throne of Andor. The eldest daughter of the queen succeeds her mother on the throne. Without a surviving daughter, the throne goes to the nearest female blood relation of the queen.

dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪt: si lænfɝ.

Daughter of the Night: See Lanfear.

doʊm ə tʃɹuθ: ɡɹeɪɾ ɑɾiəns hɔl ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt, loʊkeɪɾəd ɪn æmədɔɹ (ɑ-mɑ-dɔɹ), ðə kæpəɾəl ʌv ɑmɑdɪʃiə (ɑ-mɑ-di-tʃi-ɑ). ðəɹ ɪz ə kɪŋ ʌv ɑmɑdɪʃiə, bʌt ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ɹul ɪn ɔl bʌt neɪm. si ɔlsoʊ tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt.

Dome of Truth: Great audience hall of the Children of the Light, located in Amador (AH-mah-door), the capital of Amadicia (AH-mah-DEE-cee-ah). There is a King of Amadicia, but the Children rule in all but name. See also Children of the Light.

də maɪɹ ævɹən (doʊ mi-ɛɹ ə-vɹɔn): si wɑtʃɝz oʊvɝ ðə weɪvz.

Do Miere A'vron (DOH me-EHR a-VRAWN): See Watchers Over the Waves.

doʊmən, beɪl (doʊ-moʊn, beɪl): ðə kæptən ə ðə spɹeɪ, hu kəlɛks oʊl θɪŋz.

Domon, Bayle (DOH-mon, BAIL): The captain of the Spray, who collects old things.

dʒɹæɡkɝ (dʒɹæ-kɑɹ): ə kɹitʃɝ ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn, meɪɾ ɝɪdʒənəli baɪ twɪstɪŋ hjumən stɑk. eɪ dʒɹæɡkɝ əpɪɹz tə bi ə lɑɹdʒ mæn wɪð bæt-laɪk wɪŋz, huz skɪn ɪz tu peɪl ən huz aɪz ɑɹ tu lɑɹdʒ. ðə dʒɹæɡkɝz sɔŋ kən dʒɹɔ ɪts pɹeɪ tə ɪt, səpɹɛsɪŋ ðə vɪktəmz wɪl. ðəɹ ɪz ə seɪɪŋ: "ðə kɪs ə ðə dʒɹæɡkɝ ɪz dɛθ." ɪt dʌz nɑt baɪt, bʌɾ ɪts kɪs wɪl kənsum fɝs ðə soʊl ʌv ɪts vɪktəm, ən ðən ɪts laɪf.

Draghkar (DRAGH-kahr): A creature of the Dark One, made originally by twisting human stock. A Draghkar appears to be a large man with bat-like wings, whose skin is too pale and whose eyes are too large. The Draghkar's song can draw its prey to it, suppressing the victim's will. There is a saying: "The kiss of the Draghkar is death." It does not bite, but its kiss will consume first the soul of its victim, and then its life.

dʒɹæɡən, fɔls: əkeɪʒənəli mɛn kleɪm tə bi ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ən səmtaɪmz wʌn ə ðɛm ɡeɪnz fɑloʊɪŋ ɪnʌf tə ɹikwaɪɝ ən ɑɹmi tə pʊɾ ɪt daʊn. səm əv bɪɡʌn wɔɹz ðəɾ ɪnvɑlv mɛni neɪʃənz. oʊvɝ ðə sɛntʃɝiz moʊst ə ðiz əv bɪn mɛn əneɪbəl tə tʃænəl ðə wʌn paʊɝ, bʌɾ ə fju kəd də soʊ. ɔl, haʊɛvɝ, iðɝ dɪsəpɪɹɾ əɹ wɝ kæptʃɝɾ əɹ kɪld wɪθaʊt fʊlfɪlɪŋ ɛni ʌv ðə pɹɑfəsiz kənsɝnɪŋ ðə ɹibɝθ ə ðə dʒɹæɡən. ðiz mɛn ɑɹ kɔl fɔls dʒɹæɡənz. əmʌŋ ðoʊz u kəd tʃænəl, ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl wɝ ɹɑoʊlɪn dɑɹksbeɪn (θɹiθɝɾifaɪvθɝdisɪksæb), jʊɹiən stoʊnboʊ (sɝkə wʌnθɹizɪɹoʊzɪɹoʊwʌnθɹizɪɹoʊeɪɾ æb), dɑviən (fi θɹihʌnʒɹədfɪftiwʌn), ɡɛɹ əmɑlɑsən (fi naɪnθɹinaɪnfɔɹθɹi), ən lɑɡən (naɪnhʌnʒɹədnaɪntisɛvən ni). si ɔlsoʊ dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn.

Dragon, false: Occasionally men claim to be the Dragon Reborn, and sometimes one of them gains following enough to require an army to put it down. Some have begun wars that involved many nations. Over the centuries most of these have been men unable to channel the One Power, but a few could do so. All, however, either disappeared or were captured or killed without fulfilling any of the Prophecies concerning the Rebirth of the Dragon. These men are called false Dragons. Among those who could channel, the most powerful were Raolin Darksbane (33536AB), Yurian Stonebow (circa 13001308 AB), Davian (FY 351), Guaire Amalasan (FY 93943), and Logain (997 NE). See also Dragon Reborn.

dʒɹæɡən, pɹɑfəsiz ə ðə: lɪɾəl noʊn ən sɛldəm spoʊkən ʌv, ðə pɹɑfəsiz, ɡɪvən ɪn ðə kæɹæəθən saɪkəl, fɔɹtɛl ðət ðə dɑɹk wʌn wɪl bi fɹiɾ əɡɛn tə tʌtʃ ðə wɝld. ən ðət luz θɝɪn tɛləmən, ðə dʒɹæɡən, bɹeɪkɝ ə ðə wɝld, wɪl bi ɹibɔɹn tə faɪt tɑɹmən ɡdən, ðə læs bæɾəl əɡɛns ðə ʃædoʊ. si ɔlsoʊ dʒɹæɡən, ðə.

Dragon, Prophecies of the: Little known and seldom spoken of, the Prophecies, given in The Karaethon Cycle, foretell that the Dark One will be freed again to touch the world. And that Lews Therin Telamon, the Dragon, Breaker of the World, will be reborn to fight Tarmon Gai'don, the Last Battle against the Shadow. See also Dragon, the.

dʒɹæɡən, ðə: ðə neɪm baɪ wɪtʃ luz θɝɪn tɛləmən wɑz noʊn dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ. ɪn ðə mædnəs ðəɾ oʊvɝtʊk ɔl meɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ, luz θɝɪn kɪld ɛvɹi lɪvɪŋ pɝsən u kæɹiɾ ɛni ʌv ɪz blʌd, əz wɛl əz ɛvɹiwʌn i lʌvd, ðʌs ɝnɪŋ ðə neɪm kɪnsleɪɝ. si ɔlsoʊ dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn; dʒɹæɡən, pɹɑfəsiz ə ðə.

Dragon, the: The name by which Lews Therin Telamon was known during the War of the Shadow. In the madness that overtook all male Aes Sedai, Lews Therin killed every living person who carried any of his blood, as well as everyone he loved, thus earning the name Kinslayer. See also Dragon Reborn; Dragon, Prophecies of the.

dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn: əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə pɹɑfəsi ən lɛdʒən ðə dʒɹæɡən wɪl bi bɔɹn əɡɛn ət mænkaɪnz ɡɹeɪɾəst aʊɝ ə nid tə seɪv ðə wɝld. ðɪs ɪz nɑt sʌmθɪŋ pipəl lʊk fɔɹwɝd tə, boʊθ kəz ðə pɹɑfəsiz seɪ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɪl bɹɪŋ ə nu bɹeɪkɪŋ tə ðə wɝld ən kəz luz θɝɪn kɪnsleɪɝ, ðə dʒɹæɡən, ɪz ə neɪm tə meɪk mɛn ʃʌɾɝ, ivən mɔɹ ðən θɹi θaʊzən jɪɹz æftɝ ɪz dɛθ. si ɔlsoʊ dʒɹæɡən, ðə; dʒɹæɡən, fɔls; dʒɹæɡən, pɹɑfəsiz ə ðə.

Dragon Reborn: According to prophecy and legend the Dragon will be born again at mankind's greatest hour of need to save the world. This is not something people look forward to, both because the Prophecies say the Dragon Reborn will bring a new Breaking to the world and because Lews Therin Kinslayer, the Dragon, is a name to make men shudder, even more than three thousand years after his death. See also Dragon, the; Dragon, false; Dragon, Prophecies of the.

dʒɹæɡənz fæŋ, ðə: ə staɪlaɪz mɑɹk ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ə tɪɹdʒɹɑp bælənst ɑn ɪts pɔɪnt. skɹɔld ɑn ə dɔɹ əɹ ə haʊs, ɪts ən ækjəzeɪʃən ʌv ivəl əɡɛns ðə pipəl ɪnsaɪd, əɹ ən ətɛmp tə bɹɪŋ ðə dɑɹk wʌnz ətɛnʃən, ən ðʌs hɑɹm, tə ðɛm.

Dragon's Fang, the: A stylized mark in the shape of a teardrop balanced on its point. Scrawled on a door or a house, it is an accusation of evil against the people inside, or an attempt to bring the Dark One's attention, and thus harm, to them.

dʒɹɛdlɔɹdz: ðoʊz mɛn ən wɪmən hu, eɪbəl tə tʃænəl ðə wʌn paʊɝ, wɛn oʊvɝ tə ðə ʃædoʊ dʊɹɪŋ ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz, æktɪŋ əz kəmændɝz ə ðə tʃɹɑlɑk fɔɹsɪz.

Dreadlords: Those men and women who, able to channel the One Power, went over to the Shadow during the Trolloc Wars, acting as commanders of the Trolloc forces.

ɪleɪɾə (ɛ-laɪ-dɑ): ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌv ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ hu ædvaɪzɪz kwin mɔɹɡeɪs ʌv ændɝ. ʃi səmtaɪmz əz ðə fɔɹtɛlɪŋ. si ɔlsoʊ fɔɹtɛlɪŋ.

Elaida (eh-LY-da): An Aes Sedai of the Red Ajah who advises Queen Morgase of Andor. She sometimes has the Foretelling. See also Foretelling.

ɪleɪn (i-leɪn): kwin mɔɹɡeɪsəz dɔɾɝ, ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ tə ðə θɹoʊn ʌv ændɝ. hɝ saɪn ɪz ə ɡoʊldən lɪli.

Elayne (ee-LAIN): Queen Morgase's daughter, the Daughter-Heir to the Throne of Andor. Her sign is a golden lily.

feɪn, pdən (feɪn, pɑd-æn): ə mæn ɪmpɹɪzən əz ə dɑɹkfɹɛn ɪn fæl dæɹə kip.

Fain, Padan (FAIN, PAHD-ahn): A man imprisoned as a Darkfriend in Fal Dara keep.

fɑɹ dɛɹiz maɪ (fɑɹ dɑ-ɹaɪz maɪ): lɪɾɝəli "meɪɾənz ə ðə spɪɹ." ə wɔɹiɝ səsaɪəɾi ʌv ði il, wɪtʃ, ənlaɪk ɛni ʌv ði ʌðɝz, ədmɪts wɪmən ən oʊnli wɪmən. eɪ meɪɾən meɪ nɑt mɛɹi ən ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ðə səsaɪəɾi, nɔɹ meɪ ʃi faɪt waɪl kæɹiɪŋ ə tʃaɪld. ɛni tʃaɪl bɔɹn tə ə meɪɾən ɪz ɡɪvən tə ənʌðɝ wʊmən tə ɹeɪz, ɪn sətʃ ə weɪ ðət noʊ wʌn noʊz u ðə tʃaɪlz mʌðɝ wɑz. ("ju meɪ bɪlɔŋ tə noʊ mæn, nɔɹ meɪ ɛni mæn bɪlɔŋ tə ju, nɔɹ ɛni tʃaɪld. ðə spɪɹ ɪz jəɹ lʌvɝ, jəɹ tʃaɪld, ən jəɹ laɪf.") ðiz tʃɪlʒɹən ɑɹ tʃɹɛʒɝd, fəɹ ɪts pɹɑfəsaɪd ðəɾ ə tʃaɪl bɔɹn ʌv ə meɪɾən wɪl junaɪt ðə klænz ən ɹɪtɝn ði il tə ðə ɡɹeɪtnəs ðeɪ nu dʊɹɪŋ ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz. si ɔlsoʊ il; il wɔɹiɝ səsaɪəɾiz.

Far Dareis Mai (FAHR DAH-rize MY): Literally "Maidens of the Spear." A warrior society of the Aiel, which, unlike any of the others, admits women and only women. A Maiden may not marry and remain in the society, nor may she fight while carrying a child. Any child born to a Maiden is given to another woman to raise, in such a way that no one knows who the child's mother was. ("You may belong to no man, nor may any man belong to you, nor any child. The spear is your lover, your child, and your life.") These children are treasured, for it is prophesied that a child born of a Maiden will unite the clans and return the Aiel to the greatness they knew during the Age of Legends. See also Aiel; Aiel warrior societies.

faɪv paʊɝz, ðə: ðəɹ ɑɹ θɹɛdz tə ðə wʌn paʊɝ, ən itʃ pɝsən u kən tʃænəl kən juʒəwəli ɡɹæsp səm θɹɛdz bɛɾɝ ðən ʌðɝz. ðiz θɹɛdz ɑɹ neɪmd əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ðə sɔɹts ə θɪŋz ðət kən bi dʌn juzɪŋ əm - ɝθ, ɛɹ, faɪɝ, wɔɾɝ, ən spɪɹət - ən ɑɹ kɔl ðə faɪv paʊɝz. ɛni wildɝ ə ðə paʊɝ wɪl əv ə ɡɹeɪɾɝ dɪɡɹi ʌv stʃɹɛŋkθ wɪð wʌn, əɹ pɑsəbli tu, ʌv ðiz, ən lɛsɝ stʃɹɛŋkθ ɪn ði ʌðɝz. səm fju meɪ hæv ɡɹeɪt stʃɹɛŋkθ wɪð θɹi, bʌt sɪns ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz noʊ wʌn əz hæd ɡɹeɪt stʃɹɛŋkθ wɪð ɔl faɪv. ivən ðən ðɪs wɑz ɪkstʃɹimli ɹɛɹ. ðə dɪɡɹi ʌv stʃɹɛŋkθ kən vɛɹi ɡɹeɪtli bɪtwin ɪndəvɪdʒəwəlz, soʊ ðət səm u kən tʃænəl ɑɹ mʌtʃ stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən ʌðɝz. pɝfɔɹmɪŋ sɝɾən æks wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ ɹikwaɪɝz əbɪləɾi ɪn wʌn əɹ mɔɹ ə ðə faɪv paʊɝz. fəɹ ɪɡzæmpəl, stɑɹɾɪŋ əɹ kəntʃɹoʊlɪŋ ə faɪɝ ɹikwaɪɝz faɪɝ, ən əfɛktɪŋ ðə wɛðɝ ɹikwaɪɝz ɛɹ ən wɔɾɝ, waɪl hilɪŋ ɹikwaɪɝz wɔɾɝ ən spɪɹət. waɪl spɪɹət wɑz faʊn ikwəli ɪn mɛn ən ɪn wɪmən, ɡɹeɪɾ əbɪləɾi wɪð ɝθ ænslæʃɔɹ faɪɝ wɑz faʊn mʌtʃ mɔɹ ɔfən əmʌŋ mɛn; wɪð wɔɾɝ ænslæʃɔɹ ɛɹ əmʌŋ wɪmən. ðəɹ wɝ ɪksɛpʃənz, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz soʊ ɔfən soʊ ðəɾ ɝθ ən faɪɝ keɪm tə bi ɹəɡɑɹɾəd əz meɪl paʊɝz, ɛɹ ən wɔɾɝ əz fimeɪl. dʒɛnɝəli, noʊ əbɪləɾi ɪz kənsɪɾɝd stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən ɛni ʌðɝ, ðoʊ ðəɹ ɪz ə seɪɪŋ əmʌŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ: "ðɛɹ ɪz noʊ ɹɑk soʊ stʃɹɔŋ ðət wɔɾɝ ən wɪn kænɑt wɛɹ ɪɾ əweɪ, noʊ faɪɝ soʊ fɪɹs ðət wɔɾɝ kænɑt kwɛntʃ ɪɾ əɹ wɪn snʌf ɪɾ aʊt." ɪt ʃəd bi noʊɾəd ðɪs seɪɪŋ keɪm ɪndə jus lɔŋ æftɝ ðə læs meɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑz dɛd. ɛni ɪkwɪvələn seɪɪŋ əmʌŋ meɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪz lɔŋ lɔst.

Five Powers, the: There are threads to the One Power, and each person who can channel can usually grasp some threads better than others. These threads are named according to the sorts of things that can be done using them - Earth, Air, Fire, Water, and Spirit - and are called the Five Powers. Any wielder of the Power will have a greater degree of strength with one, or possibly two, of these, and lesser strength in the others. Some few may have great strength with three, but since the Age of Legends no one has had great strength with all five. Even then this was extremely rare. The degree of strength can vary greatly between individuals, so that some who can channel are much stronger than others. Performing certain acts with the One Power requires ability in one or more of the Five Powers. For example, starting or controlling a fire requires Fire, and affecting the weather requires Air and Water, while Healing requires Water and Spirit. While Spirit was found equally in men and in women, great ability with Earth and/or Fire was found much more often among men; with Water and/or Air among women. There were exceptions, but it was so often so that Earth and Fire came to be regarded as male Powers, Air and Water as female. Generally, no ability is considered stronger than any other, though there is a saying among Aes Sedai: "There is no rock so strong that water and wind cannot wear it away, no fire so fierce that water cannot quench it or wind snuff it out." It should be noted this saying came into use long after the last male Aes Sedai was dead. Any equivalent saying among male Aes Sedai is long lost.

fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn: ðə sɪmbəl ə tɑɹ vəlɑn, ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ə staɪlaɪzd ɹɛpɹəzɛnteɪʃən ʌv ə fleɪm; ə waɪt tɪɹdʒɹɑp wɪð ðə pɔɪn ʌpwɝd.

Flame of Tar Valon: The symbol of Tar Valon, the Amyrlin Seat, and the Aes Sedai. A stylized representation of a flame; a white teardrop with the point upward.

fɔɹseɪkən, ðə: neɪm ɡɪvən tə θɝtin ə ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl ɛɛs sədaɪ ɛvɝ noʊn, hu wɛn oʊvɝ tə ðə dɑɹk wʌn dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ ɪn ɹɪtɝn fəɹ ðə pɹɑməs ʌv ɪmɔɹtælɪɾi. əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə boʊθ lɛdʒən ən fɹæɡməntɛɹi ɹɛkɝdz, ðeɪ wɝ ɪmpɹɪzən əlɔŋ wɪð ðə dɑɹk wʌn wən ɪz pɹɪzən wɑz ɹisild. ðɛɹ neɪmz ɑɹ stɪl juz tə fɹaɪɾən tʃɪlʒɹən.

Forsaken, the: Name given to thirteen of the most powerful Aes Sedai ever known, who went over to the Dark One during the War of the Shadow in return for the promise of immortality. According to both legend and fragmentary records, they were imprisoned along with the Dark One when his prison was resealed. Their names are still used to frighten children.

ɡeɪɾɪn (ɡaɪ-din): lɪɾɝəli, "bɹʌðɝ tə bæɾəlz." ə taɪɾəl juz baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ fəɹ ðə wɔɹɾɝz. si ɔlsoʊ wɔɹɾɝ.

Gaidin (GYE-deen): Literally, "Brother to Battles." A title used by Aes Sedai for the Warders. See also Warder.

ɡɑləd (ɡɑ-lɑd): si dəmədʒɹd, lɔɹd ɡɑleɪdɛdʒɹəd.

Galad (gah-LAHD): See Damodred, Lord Galadedrid.

ɡɔlʒɹiən su ɹieɪɾən ɹi (ɡɑl-dʒɹi-æn su ɹeɪaɪ-ɑ-tɪn ɹi): lɪɾɝəli, ɡɔlʒɹiən ə haʊs ɹieɪɾən, kɪŋ. kɪŋ ə kɛɹhin. si ɔlsoʊ kɛɹhin.

Galldrian su Riatin Rie (GAHL-dree-ahn soo REYE-ah-tin REE): Literally, Galldrian of House Riatin, King. King of Cairhien. See also Cairhien.

ɡeɪm ə haʊzɪz, ðə: si deɪz deɪmɑɹ.

Game of Houses, the: See Daes Dae'mar.

ɡɔɪn (ɡɑ-wɪn): kwin mɔɹɡeɪsəz sʌn, ən ɪleɪnz bɹʌðɝ. hɪz saɪn ɪz ə waɪt bɔɹ.

Gawyn (GAH-wihn): Queen Morgase's son, and Elayne's brother. His sign is a white boar.

dʒɛntəlɪŋ: ði ækt, pɝfɔɹm baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ʌv ʃʌɾɪŋ ɔf ə meɪl u kən tʃænəl fɹəm ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ðɪs ɪz nɛsəsɛɹi kəz ɛni mæn u lɝnz tə tʃænəl wɪl ɡoʊ ɪnseɪn fɹəm ðə teɪn ɑn seɪɾɪn ən wɪl ɔlmoʊst sɝɾənli də hɔɹəbəl θɪŋz wɪð ðə paʊɝ ɪn ɪz mædnəs. ə mæn u hæz bɪn dʒɛntəl kən stɪl sɛns ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs, bʌɾ i kænɑt tʌtʃ ɪt. wʌtɛvɝ mædnəs əz kʌm bɪfɔɹ dʒɛntəlɪŋ ɪz ɝɛstəd baɪ ði ækt ə dʒɛntəlɪŋ, bʌt nɑt kjʊɹd baɪ ɪt, ən ɪf ɪts dʌn sun ɪnʌf dɛθ kən bi əvɝɾəd. si ɔlsoʊ wʌn paʊɝ, ðə; stɪlɪŋ.

gentling: The act, performed by Aes Sedai, of shutting off a male who can channel from the One Power. This is necessary because any man who learns to channel will go insane from the taint on saidin and will almost certainly do horrible things with the Power in his madness. A man who has been gentled can still sense the True Source, but he cannot touch it. Whatever madness has come before gentling is arrested by the act of gentling, but not cured by it, and if it is done soon enough death can be averted. See also One Power, the; stilling.

ɡlimən: ə tʃɹævlɪŋ stɔɹitɛlɝ, mjuzɪʃən, dʒʌɡəlɝ, tʌmblɝ, ən ɔl-ɝaʊn ɛntɝteɪnɝ. noʊn baɪ ðɛɹ tʃɹeɪdmɑɹk kloʊks ə mɛni-kʌlɝd pætʃəz, ðeɪ pɝfɔɹm meɪnli ɪn ðə vɪlədʒəz ən smɔlɝ taʊnz.

gleeman: A traveling storyteller, musician, juggler, tumbler, and all-around entertainer. Known by their trademark cloaks of many-colored patches, they perform mainly in the villages and smaller towns.

ɡoʊbən (ɡoʊ-ɑ-bæn): wʌn ə ðə neɪʃənz ɹʌŋ fɹəm ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz ɛmpaɪɝ dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz. ɪt wikənd, ən feɪɾəd əweɪ əpɹɑksəmətli faɪvhʌnʒɹəd ni. si ɔlsoʊ ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ; wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz.

Goaban (GO-ah-banh): One of the nations wrung from Artur Hawkwing's empire during the War of the Hundred Years. It weakened, and faded away approximately 500 NE. See also Artur Hawkwing; War of the Hundred Years.

ɡɹeɪt blaɪt, ðə: ə ɹidʒən ɪn ðə fɑɹ nɔɹθ, ɪntaɪɝli kɝʌptɪd baɪ ðə dɑɹk wʌn. ə hɔn ə tʃɹɑləks, mɹdʒɹɑl, ən ʌðɝ kɹitʃɝz ə ðə ʃædoʊ.

Great Blight, the: A region in the far north, entirely corrupted by the Dark One. A haunt of Trollocs, Myrddraal, and other creatures of the Shadow.

ɡɹeɪt ɡeɪm, ðə: si deɪz deɪmɑɹ.

Great Game, the: See Daes Dae'mar.

ɡɹeɪt hʌn ə ðə hɔɹn, ðə: ə saɪkəl ə stɔɹiz kənsɝnɪŋ ðə lɛdʒəndɛɹi sɝtʃ fəɹ ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ, ɪn ðə jɪɹz bɪtwin ði ɛn ə ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz ən ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ ə ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz. ɪf toʊld ɪn ɪts ɪntaɪɝɾi, ðə saɪkəl wəd teɪk mɛni deɪz.

Great Hunt of the Horn, The: A cycle of stories concerning the legendary search for the Horn of Valere, in the years between the end of the Trolloc Wars and the beginning of the War of the Hundred Years. If told in its entirety, the cycle would take many days.

ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ ə ðə dɑɹk: ðə neɪm baɪ wɪtʃ dɑɹkfɹɛnz ɹəfɝ tə ðə dɑɹk wʌn, kleɪmɪŋ ðət tə juz ɪz tʃɹu neɪm wəd bi blæsfəməs.

Great Lord of the Dark: The name by which Darkfriends refer to the Dark One, claiming that to use his true name would be blasphemous.

ɡɹeɪt sɝpənt: ə sɪmbəl fəɹ taɪm ən ɪtɝnəɾi, eɪntʃən bɪfɔɹ ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz bɪɡæn, kənsɪstɪŋ ʌv ə sɝpən iɾɪŋ ɪts oʊn teɪl. ə ɹɪŋ ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ə ðə ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɪz əwɔɹɾəd tə wɪmən u hæv bɪn ɹeɪz tə ði æksɛptɪɾ əmʌŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Great Serpent: A symbol for time and eternity, ancient before the Age of Legends began, consisting of a serpent eating its own tail. A ring in the shape of the Great Serpent is awarded to women who have been raised to the Accepted among the Aes Sedai.

heɪlin (haɪ-li-nɛ): ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "ðoʊz u kʌm bɪfɔɹ," əɹ "fɔɹʌnɝz."

Hailene (heye-LEE-neh): In the Old Tongue, "Those Who Come Before," or "Forerunners."

hæfmən: si mɹdʒɹɑl.

Halfman: See Myrddraal.

hɑɹɾən: wʌn ə ðə neɪʃənz ɹʌŋ fɹəm ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz ɛmpaɪɝ, naʊ lɔŋ fɝɡɑɾən. ɪt leɪ bɪtwin kɛɹhin ən ʃaɪnɝ.

Hardan: One of the nations wrung from Artur Hawkwing's empire, now long forgotten. It lay between Cairhien and Shienar.

hɔkwɪŋ, ɑɹɾɝ: ə lɛdʒəndɛɹi kɪŋ (ɹul fi naɪnfɔɹθɹinaɪnnaɪnfɔɹ) hu junaɪɾəd ɔl ðə lænz wɛst ə ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝld. hi ivən sɛn ɑɹmiz əkɹɔs ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən (fi naɪnhʌnʒɹədnaɪntitu), bʌɾ ɔl kɑntækt wɪð ðiz wɑz lɔst əɾ ɪz dɛθ, wɪtʃ sɛɾ ɔf ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz. hɪz saɪn wɑz ə ɡoʊldən hɔk ɪn flaɪt. si ɔlsoʊ wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz.

Hawkwing, Artur: A legendary king (ruled FY 943994) who united all the lands west of the Spine of the World. He even sent armies across the Aryth Ocean (FY 992), but all contact with these was lost at his death, which set off the War of the Hundred Years. His sign was a golden hawk in flight. See also War of the Hundred Years.

hɑɹtstoʊn: ən ɪndəstʃɹʌktɪbəl sʌbstəns kɹieɪɾəd dʊɹɪŋ ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz. ɛni fɔɹs juzd ɪn ən ətɛmp tə bɹeɪk ɪts əbzɔɹbd, meɪkɪŋ hɑɹtstoʊn stʃɹɔŋɝ. si ɔlsoʊ kwəndɪlɝ.

heartstone: An indestructible substance created during the Age of Legends. Any force used in an attempt to break it is absorbed, making heartstone stronger. See also cuendillar.

haɪd: ə junəɾ ʌv ɛɹiə fəɹ mɛʒɝɪŋ lænd, ikwəl tə wʌnhʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz baɪ wʌnhʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz.

hide: A unit of area for measuring land, equal to 100 paces by 100 paces.

hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ (vɑ-lɪɹ): ðə lɛdʒəndɛɹi əbdʒɛkt ə ðə ɡɹeɪt hʌn ə ðə hɔɹn. ðə hɔɹn səpoʊzədli kən kɔl bæk dɛd hɪɹoʊz fɹəm ðə ɡɹeɪv tə faɪɾ əɡɛns ðə ʃædoʊ.

Horn of Valere (vah-LEER): The legendary object of the Great Hunt of the Horn. The Horn supposedly can call back dead heroes from the grave to fight against the Shadow.

hʌnʒɹəd kəmpænjənz, ðə: wʌn hʌnʒɹəd meɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ, əmʌŋ ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl ə ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz, hu, lɛd baɪ luz θɝɪn tɛləmən, lɔntʃt ðə faɪnəl stʃɹoʊk ðəɾ ɛndəd ðə wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ baɪ silɪŋ ðə dɑɹk wʌn bæk ɪndə hɪz pɹɪzən. ðə dɑɹk wʌnz kaʊntɝstʃɹoʊk teɪntɪd seɪɾɪn; ðə hʌnʒɹəd kəmpænjənz wɛn mæɾ ən bɪɡæn ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld. si ɔlsoʊ taɪm ə mædnəs; bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld; tʃɹu sɔɹs; wʌn paʊɝ.

Hundred Companions, the: One hundred male Aes Sedai, among the most powerful of the Age of Legends, who, led by Lews Therin Telamon, launched the final stroke that ended the War of the Shadow by sealing the Dark One back into his prison. The Dark One's counterstroke tainted saidin; the Hundred Companions went mad and began the Breaking of the World. See also Time of Madness; Breaking of the World; True Source; One Power.

hʊɹɪn (hju-ɹɪn): eɪ ʃaɪnɝən u hæz ði əbɪləɾi tə smɛl wɛɹ vaɪələns əz bɪn dʌn, ən tə fɑloʊ ðə sɛn ə ðoʊz u dɪɾ ɪt. kɔld ə "snɪfɝ," hi sɝvz ðə kɪŋz dʒʌstəs ɪn fæl dæɹə, ɪn ʃaɪnɝ.

Hurin (HEW-rhin): A Shienaran who has the ability to smell where violence has been done, and to follow the scent of those who did it. Called a "sniffer," he serves the King's justice in Fal Dara, in Shienar.

ɪljən (ɪl-li-æn): ə ɡɹeɪt pɔɹɾ ɑn ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz, kæpəɾəl sɪɾi ʌv ðə neɪʃən ə ðə seɪm neɪm.

Illian (IHL-lee-ahn): A great port on the Sea of Storms, capital city of the nation of the same name.

ɪŋtʃɹ, lɔɹd, ʌv haʊs ʃɪnoʊwə (ɪŋ-tɑɹ); (ʃi-noʊ-wɑ): eɪ ʃaɪnɝən wɔɹiɝ. hɪz saɪn ɪz ðə ɡɹeɪ aʊl.

Ingtar, Lord, of House Shinowa (IHNG-tahr); (shih-NOH-wah): A Shienaran warrior. His sign is the Gray Owl.

ɪʃəml (ɪ-ʃɑ-meɪ-ɛl): ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "bɪtʃɹeɪɝ ə hoʊp." wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən. neɪm ɡɪvən tə ðə liɾɝ ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hu wɛn oʊvɝ tə ðə dɑɹk wʌn ɪn ðə wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ. ɪts sɛd ðəɾ ivən i fɝɡɑɾ ɪz tʃɹu neɪm. si ɔlsoʊ fɔɹseɪkən.

Ishamael (ih-SHAH-may-EHL): In the Old Tongue, "Betrayer of Hope." One of the Forsaken. Name given to the leader of the Aes Sedai who went over to the Dark One in the War of the Shadow. It is said that even he forgot his true name. See also Forsaken.

kæɹæəθən saɪkəl, ðə (kɑ-ɹi-ɑ-θɑn): si dʒɹæɡən, pɹɑfəsiz ə ðə.

Karaethon Cycle, The (ka-REE-ah-thon): See Dragon, Prophecies of the.

kɪθ: kloʊs fɹɛnz ən əkweɪntənsɪz.

kith: Close friends and acquaintances.

leɪmən (leɪ-mæn): ə kɪŋ ə kɛɹhin, ʌv haʊs dəmədʒɹd, hu lɔst ɪz θɹoʊn ən laɪf ɪn ði il wɔɹ.

Laman (LAY-mahn): A king of Cairhien, of House Damodred, who lost his throne and life in the Aiel War.

læn; ælən mænʒɹɑɡɔɹən (ɑl-læn mæn-dʒɹæɡ-ɔɹ-æn): eɪ wɔɹɾɝ, bɑndəd tə mɔɪɹeɪn. ʌnkɹoʊn kɪŋ ə mɔlkiɝ, daɪ ʃæn, ən ðə læst sɝvaɪvɪŋ mɔlkɪɹi lɔɹd. si ɔlsoʊ wɔɹɾɝ; mɔɪɹeɪn; mɔlkiɝ; daɪ ʃæn.

Lan; al'Lan Mandragoran (AHL-LAN man-DRAG-or-an): A Warder, bonded to Moiraine. Uncrowned King of Malkier, Dai Shan, and the last surviving Malkieri lord. See also Warder; Moiraine; Malkier; Dai Shan.

lænfɝ (læn-fɪɹ): ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪt." wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən, pɝhæps ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl nɛks tə ɪʃəml. ənlaɪk ði ʌðɝ fɔɹseɪkən, ʃi tʃoʊz ðɪs neɪm hɝsɛlf. ʃiz sɛd tə hæv bɪn ɪn lʌv wɪð luz θɝɪn tɛləmən. si ɔlsoʊ fɔɹseɪkən; dʒɹæɡən, ðə.

Lanfear (LAN-fear): In the Old Tongue, "Daughter of the Night." One of the Forsaken, perhaps the most powerful next to Ishamael. Unlike the other Forsaken, she chose this name herself. She is said to have been in love with Lews Therin Telamon. See also Forsaken; Dragon, the.

liɡ: si lɛŋθ, junəts ʌv.

league: See Length, units of.

lin (li-æn-ɛ): ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌv ðə blu ədʒɑ, ən kipɝ ə ðə kɹɑnəkəlz. si ɔlsoʊ ədʒɑ; kɹɑnəkəlz, kipɝ ə ðə.

Leane (lee-AHN-eh): An Aes Sedai of the Blue Ajah, and Keeper of the Chronicles. See also Ajah; Chronicles, Keeper of the.

liʃt wʌnz: si deɪmeɪn.

Leashed Ones: See damane.

lɛŋθ, junəts ʌv: tɛn ɪntʃəz ikwəlz θɹi hænz ikwəlz wʌn fʊt; θɹi fiɾ ikwəlz wʌn peɪs; tu peɪsɪz ikwəlz wʌn spæn; wʌnθaʊzən spænz ikwəlz wʌn maɪl; fɔɹ maɪlz ikwəlz wʌn liɡ.

Length, units of: 10 inches = 3 hands = 1 foot; 3 feet = 1 pace; 2 paces = 1 span; 1000 spans = 1 mile; 4 miles = 1 league.

luz θɝɪn tɛləmən; luz θɝɪn kɪnsleɪɝ: si dʒɹæɡən, ðə.

Lews Therin Telamon; Lews Therin Kinslayer: See Dragon, the.

liɑnʒɹɪn (li-æn-dʒɹɪn): ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌv ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ, fɹəm tæɹɑbən.

Liandrin (lee-AHN-drihn): An Aes Sedai of the Red Ajah, from Tarabon.

lɑɡən (loʊ-ɡeɪn): ə fɔls dʒɹæɡən, dʒɛntəl baɪ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Logain (loh-GAYN): A false Dragon, gentled by the Aes Sedai.

lɔɪəl (lɔɪ-ɑl): ən oʊɡiɝ fɹəm stɛɾɪŋ ʃæŋktaɪ.

Loial (LOY-ahl): An Ogier from Stedding Shangtai.

luk; lɔɹd luk ə haʊs mæntʃɹ (luk; mæn-ti-ɑɹ): tɪɡɹeɪnz bɹʌðɝ. hɪz dɪsəpɪɹəns ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪt blaɪt (naɪnhʌnʒɹədsɛvəntiwʌn ni) ɪz bɪliv tə bi kənɛktəd tə tɪɡɹeɪnz leɪɾɝ dɪsəpɪɹəns. hɪz saɪn wɑz ən eɪkɔɹn.

Luc; Lord Luc of House Mantear (LUKE; MAN-tee-ahr): Tigraine's brother. His disappearance in the Great Blight (971 NE) is believed to be connected to Tigraine's later disappearance. His sign was an acorn.

luthɛɹ: si mɑndwɪn, luthɛɹ pɛndʒɹæɡ.

Luthair: See Mondwin, Luthair Paendrag.

mɔlkiɝ (mɑl-kiɪɹ): ə neɪʃən, wʌns wʌn ə ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz, naʊ kənsum baɪ ðə blaɪt. ðə saɪn ə mɔlkiɝ wɑz ə ɡoʊldən kɹeɪn ɪn flaɪt.

Malkier (mahl-KEER): A nation, once one of the Borderlands, now consumed by the Blight. The sign of Malkier was a golden crane in flight.

meɪnɛðɝən (mæn--ɛɹ-ɛn): wʌn ə ðə tɛn neɪʃənz ðət meɪd ðə sɛkən kʌvənənt, ən ɔlsoʊ ðə kæpəɾəl sɪɾi ʌv ðət neɪʃən. boʊθ sɪɾi ən neɪʃən wɝ ʌɾɝli dɪstʃɹɔɪɾ ɪn ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz.

Manetheren (mahn-EHTH-ehr-ehn): One of the Ten Nations that made the Second Covenant, and also the capital city of that nation. Both city and nation were utterly destroyed in the Trolloc Wars.

mɛɹəθdəmeɪn (mɑ-ɹɑθdə-mæn-i): ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "ðoʊz u mʌs bi liʃt." tɝm juz baɪ ðə sintʃæn fəɹ wɪmən u kən tʃænəl, bʌɾ u hæv nɑt jɛt bɪn kæptʃɝɾ ən kɑlɝd. si ɔlsoʊ deɪmeɪn; æɾəm; sintʃæn.

marath'damane (MAH-rahth'dah-MAHN-ee): In the Old Tongue, "Those Who Must Be Leashed." Term used by the Seanchan for women who can channel, but who have not yet been captured and collared. See also damane; a'dam; Seanchan.

mæsimə (mɑ-si-mɑ): eɪ ʃaɪnɝən soʊlʒɝ u heɪts il.

Masema (mah-SEE-mah): A Shienaran soldier who hates Aiel.

mæʃiɑɹə (mɑ-ʃi-ɑ-ɹɑ): ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "bɪlʌvd," bʌt minɪŋ ə lʌv ðəɾ ɪz lɔs bɪɑn ɹɪdimɪŋ.

mashiara (mah-shee-AH-rah): In the Old Tongue, "beloved," but meaning a love that is lost beyond redeeming.

mɛɹɪlɪn, tɑm (mɛɹ-ɹɪ-lɪn, tɑm): ə ɡlimən.

Merrilin, Thom (MER-rih-lihn, TOM): A gleeman.

maɪl: si lɛŋθ, junəts ʌv.

mile: See Length, units of.

mɪn (mɪn): ə jʌŋ wʊmən wɪð ði əbɪləɾi tə ɹid ði ɔʊɹəz ʃi səmtaɪmz siz sɝaʊndɪŋ pipəl.

Min (MIN): A young woman with the ability to read the auras she sometimes sees surrounding people.

mɔɪɹeɪn (mwɑ-ɹeɪn): ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌv ðə blu ədʒɑ.

Moiraine (mwah-RAIN): An Aes Sedai of the Blue Ajah.

mɑndwɪn, luthɛɹ pɛndʒɹæɡ (lu-thɛɹ peɪ-ɛn-dʒɹæɡ moʊn-dwɪn): sʌn ʌv ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ, hi kəmændəd ði ɑɹmiz hɔkwɪŋ sɛn əkɹɔs ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən. hɪz bænɝ wɑz ə ɡoʊldən, spɹɛd-wɪŋ hɔk klʌtʃɪŋ laɪtnɪŋ boʊls. si ɔlsoʊ hɔkwɪŋ, ɑɹɾɝ.

Mondwin, Luthair Paendrag (LEW-thair PAY-ehn-DRAG MON-dwihn): Son of Artur Hawkwing, he commanded the armies Hawkwing sent across the Aryth Ocean. His banner was a golden, spread-winged hawk clutching lightning bolts. See also Hawkwing, Artur.

mɔɹɾɪθ (mʊɹ-dɛθ): kaʊnsəlɝ u tɝn ðə sɪɾi ʌv ɑɹɪdhɔl tə juz dɑɹkfɹɛnz' weɪz əɡɛns ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz, ðʌs bɹɪŋɪŋ ɪts dɪstʃɹʌkʃən ən ɝnɪŋ ɪɾ ə nu neɪm, ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ ("wɛɹ ðə ʃædoʊ weɪts"). oʊnli wʌn θɪŋ sɝvaɪvz ɪn ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ bɪsaɪd ðə heɪt ðət kɪld ɪt, ən ðəɾ ɪz mɔɹɾɪθ hɪmsɛlf, baʊn ɪn ðə ɹuənz fəɹ tu θaʊzən jɪɹz, weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ sʌmwʌn tə kʌm huz soʊl i kən kənsum ən soʊ teɪk ɑn nu flɛʃ.

Mordeth (MOOR-death): Councilor who turned the city of Aridhol to use Darkfriends' ways against the Darkfriends, thus bringing its destruction and earning it a new name, Shadar Logoth ("Where the Shadow Waits"). Only one thing survives in Shadar Logoth beside the hate that killed it, and that is Mordeth himself, bound in the ruins for two thousand years, waiting for someone to come whose soul he can consume and so take on new flesh.

mɔɹɡeɪs (mʊɹ-ɡeɪz): kwin ʌv ændɝ, haɪ siɾ ə haʊs tʃɹəkənd (-ɑnd).

Morgase (moor-GAYZ): Queen of Andor, High Seat of House Trakand (TRAHK-ahnd).

mɹdʒɹɑl (-dʒɹɑl): kɹitʃɝz ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn, kəmændɝz ə ðə tʃɹɑləks. twɪstəɾ ɔfspɹɪŋ ə tʃɹɑləks ɪn wɪtʃ ðə hjumən stɑk juz tə kɹieɪt ðə tʃɹɑləks əz ɹisɝfəst, bʌt teɪntɪd baɪ ði ivəl ðət meɪd ðə tʃɹɑləks. fɪzɪkəli ðeɪ ɑɹ laɪk mɛn ɪksɛp ðeɪv noʊ aɪz, bʌt kən si laɪk iɡəlz ɪn laɪɾ əɹ dɑɹk. ðeɪv sɝɾən paʊɝz stɛmɪŋ fɹəm ðə dɑɹk wʌn, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ði əbɪləɾi tə kɑz pɛɹəlaɪzɪŋ fɪɹ wɪð ə lʊk ən ði əbɪləɾi tə vænɪʃ wɛɹɛvɝ ðəɹ ɑɹ ʃædoʊz. wʌn ə ðɛɹ fju noʊn wiknəsəz ɪz ðət ðeɪ ɑɹ ɹɪlʌktən tə kɹɔs ɹʌnɪŋ wɔɾɝ. ɪn dɪfɹən lænz ðeɪ ɑɹ noʊn baɪ mɛni neɪmz, əmʌŋ əm hæfmən, ði aɪləs, ʃæɾoʊmən, lɝks, ən feɪdz.

Myrddraal (MUHRD-draal): Creatures of the Dark One, commanders of the Trollocs. Twisted offspring of Trollocs in which the human stock used to create the Trollocs has resurfaced, but tainted by the evil that made the Trollocs. Physically they are like men except they have no eyes, but can see like eagles in light or dark. They have certain powers stemming from the Dark One, including the ability to cause paralyzing fear with a look and the ability to vanish wherever there are shadows. One of their few known weaknesses is that they are reluctant to cross running water. In different lands they are known by many names, among them Halfmen, the Eyeless, Shadowmen, Lurks, and Fades.

naɪl, peɪdʒɹən (naɪ-ɔl, peɪ-dʒɹɑn): lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt. si ɔlsoʊ tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt.

Niall, Pedron (NEYE-awl, PAY-drohn): Lord Captain Commander of the Children of the Light. See also Children of the Light.

nɪʃʊɹə, leɪɾi (ɛnaɪeɪtʃ-su-ɹɑ): eɪ ʃaɪnɝən noʊbəlwʊmən, ən wʌn ə ðə leɪɾi əmælisəz ətɛndəns.

Nisura, Lady (nih-SOO-rah): A Shienaran noblewoman, and one of the Lady Amalisa's attendants.

wʌn paʊɝ, ðə: ðə paʊɝ dʒɹɔn fɹəm ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs. ðə væs mədʒɔɹəɾi ʌv pipəl ɑɹ kəmplitli əneɪbəl tə lɝn tə tʃænəl ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ə vɛɹi smɔl nʌmbɝ kən bi tɔt tə tʃænəl, ən ən ivən taɪniɝ nʌmbɝ əv ði əbɪləɾi ɪnbɔɹn. fəɹ ðiz fju ðəɹ ɪz noʊ nid tə bi tɔt; ðəl tʌtʃ ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs ən tʃænəl ðə paʊɝ wɛðɝ ðeɪ wɑnə əɹ nɑt, pɝhæps wɪθaʊɾ ivən ɹilaɪzɪŋ wʌt ðeɪ ɑɹ duɪŋ. ðɪs ɪnbɔɹn əbɪləɾi juʒəwəli mænəfɛsts ɪtsɛlf ɪn leɪɾ æɾəlɛsəns əɹ ɝli ədʌlthʊd. ɪf kəntʃɹoʊl ɪz nɑt tɔt, əɹ sɛlf-lɝnd (ɪkstʃɹimli dɪfəkəlt, wɪð ə səksɛs ɹeɪɾ ʌv oʊnli wʌn ɪn fɔɹ), dɛθ ɪz sɝɾən. sɪns ðə taɪm ə mædnəs, noʊ mæn əz bɪn eɪbəl tə tʃænəl ðə paʊɝ wɪθaʊɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli ɡoʊɪŋ kəmplitli, hɔɹəbli mæd, ən ðɛn, ivən ɪf hiz lɝn səm kəntʃɹoʊl, daɪɪŋ fɹəm ə weɪstɪŋ sɪknəs ðət kɑzəz ðə sʌfɝɝ tə ɹɑɾ əlaɪv, ə sɪknəs kɑzd, əz ɪz ðə mædnəs, baɪ ðə dɑɹk wʌnz teɪn ɑn seɪɾɪn. fəɹ ə wʊmən ðə dɛθ ðət kʌmz wɪθaʊt kəntʃɹoʊl ə ðə paʊɝ ɪz lɛs hɔɹəbəl, bʌɾ ɪts dɛθ dʒʌs ðə seɪm. ɛɛs sədaɪ sɝtʃ fəɹ ɡɝlz wɪð ði ɪnbɔɹn əbɪləɾi əz mʌtʃ tə seɪv ðɛɹ laɪvz əz tə ɪnkɹis ɛɛs sədaɪ nʌmbɝz, ən fəɹ mɛn wɪð ɪɾ ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə stɑp ðə tɛɹəbəl θɪŋz ðeɪ ɪnɛvəɾəbli də wɪð ðə paʊɝ ɪn ðɛɹ mædnəs. si ɔlsoʊ tʃænəl; taɪm ə mædnəs; tʃɹu sɔɹs.

One Power, the: The power drawn from the True Source. The vast majority of people are completely unable to learn to channel the One Power. A very small number can be taught to channel, and an even tinier number have the ability inborn. For these few there is no need to be taught; they will touch the True Source and channel the Power whether they want to or not, perhaps without even realizing what they are doing. This inborn ability usually manifests itself in late adolescence or early adulthood. If control is not taught, or self-learned (extremely difficult, with a success rate of only one in four), death is certain. Since the Time of Madness, no man has been able to channel the Power without eventually going completely, horribly mad, and then, even if he has learned some control, dying from a wasting sickness that causes the sufferer to rot alive, a sickness caused, as is the madness, by the Dark One's taint on saidin. For a woman the death that comes without control of the Power is less horrible, but it is death just the same. Aes Sedai search for girls with the inborn ability as much to save their lives as to increase Aes Sedai numbers, and for men with it in order to stop the terrible things they inevitably do with the Power in their madness. See also channel; Time of Madness; True Source.

pæɾɝn ʌv ən eɪdʒ: ðə wil ə taɪm wivz ðə θɹɛdz ə hjumən lɪvz ɪndə ðə pæɾɝn ʌv ən eɪdʒ, ɔfən kɔl sɪmpli ðə pæɾɝn, wɪtʃ fɔɹmz ðə sʌbstəns ə ɹiæləɾi fəɹ ðəɾ eɪdʒ. si ɔlsoʊ tɑvɝən.

Pattern of an Age: The Wheel of Time weaves the threads of human lives into the Pattern of an Age, often called simply the Pattern, which forms the substance of reality for that Age. See also ta'veren.

paʊɝz, ðə faɪv: si faɪv paʊɝz.

Powers, the Five: See Five Powers.

kwɛstʃənɝz, ðə: ən ɔɹɾɝ wɪðɪn ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt. ðɛɹ əvaʊd pɝpəsəz ɑɹ tə dɪskʌvɝ ðə tʃɹuθ ɪn dɪspjəteɪʃənz ən tə ənkʌvɝ dɑɹkfɹɛnz. ɪn ðə sɝtʃ fəɹ tʃɹuθ ən ðə laɪt, ðɛɹ nɔɹməl mɛθəɾ ʌv ɪnkwaɪɹi ɪz baɪ tɔɹtʃɝ; ðɛɹ nɔɹməl æɾətud ðət ðeɪ noʊ ðə tʃɹuθ ɔlɹɛɾi ən mʌst oʊnli meɪk ðɛɹ vɪktəm kənfɛs tə ɪt. ðə kwɛstʃənɝz ɹəfɝ tə ðɛmsɛlvz əz ðə hæn ə ðə laɪt, ðə hæn ðət dɪɡz aʊt tʃɹuθ, ən ət taɪmz ækt əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ ɪntaɪɝli sɛpɹət fɹəm ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ən ðə kaʊnsəl ə ði ənɔɪntəd, wɪtʃ kəmænz ðə tʃɪlʒɹən. ðə hɛɾ ə ðə kwɛstʃənɝz ɪz ðə haɪ ɪnkwɪzəɾɝ, hu sɪts ɑn ðə kaʊnsəl ə ði ənɔɪntəd. ðɛɹ saɪn ɪz ə blʌd-ɹɛd ʃɛpɝdz kɹʊk.

Questioners, the: An order within the Children of the Light. Their avowed purposes are to discover the truth in disputations and to uncover Darkfriends. In the search for truth and the Light, their normal method of inquiry is by torture; their normal attitude that they know the truth already and must only make their victim confess to it. The Questioners refer to themselves as the Hand of the Light, the Hand that digs out truth, and at times act as if they were entirely separate from the Children and the Council of the Anointed, which commands the Children. The head of the Questioners is the High Inquisitor, who sits on the Council of the Anointed. Their sign is a blood-red shepherd's crook.

ɹeɪɡən (ɹɑ-ɡæn): eɪ ʃaɪnɝən wɔɹiɝ.

Ragan (rah-GAHN): A Shienaran warrior.

ɹɛd ʃilz: si il wɔɹiɝ səsaɪəɾiz.

Red Shields: See Aiel warrior societies.

ɹɛnə (ɹin-nɑ): eɪ sintʃæn wʊmən; ə sʌldəm. si ɔlsoʊ sintʃæn; sʌldəm.

Renna (REEN-nah): A Seanchan woman; a sul'dam. See also Seanchan; sul'dam.

ɹaɪædʒɛl (ɹiaɪ-ɑ-ɡɛl): ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "ðoʊz u kʌm hoʊm," əɹ "hoʊmkəmɝz."

Rhyagelle (rheye-ah-GEHL): In the Old Tongue, "Those Who Come Home," or "Homecomers."

sɑŋɡɹil (sɑ-æn-ɡɹi-ɑl): ɛni wʌn ʌv ə nʌmbɝ ʌv ɑbʒɛkts ðəɾ əlaʊ ən ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl tə tʃænəl mʌtʃ mɔɹ ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ ðən wəɾ ʌðɝwaɪz bi pɑsəbəl əɹ seɪf. ə sɑŋɡɹil ɪz laɪk ʌntu, bʌt mʌtʃ mɔɹ paʊɝfəl ðæn, ən æŋɡɹil. ði əmaʊn ə ðə paʊɝ ðət kən bi wildɪd wɪð ə sɑŋɡɹil kəmpɛɹz tə ði əmaʊn ə ðə paʊɝ ðət kən bi hændəld wɪð ən æŋɡɹil əz ðə paʊɝ wildɪd wɪð ði eɪɾ ʌv ən æŋɡɹil dʌz tə ði əmaʊn ə ðə paʊɝ ðət kən bi hændəld əneɪɾɪd. ɹɛmnəns ə ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz, ðə minz ə meɪkɪŋ sɑŋɡɹil ɪz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ noʊn. oʊnli ə hændfʊl ɹɪmeɪn, fɑɹ fjuɝ ivən ðən æŋɡɹil.

sa'angreal (SAH-ahn-GREE-ahl): Any one of a number of objects that allow an individual to channel much more of the One Power than would otherwise be possible or safe. A sa'angreal is like unto, but much more powerful than, an angreal. The amount of the Power that can be wielded with a sa'angreal compares to the amount of the Power that can be handled with an angreal as the Power wielded with the aid of an angreal does to the amount of the Power that can be handled unaided. Remnants of the Age of Legends, the means of making sa'angreal is no longer known. Only a handful remain, far fewer even than angreal.

seɪaɪdɑɹ (sɑ-ɪ-dɑɹ): seɪɾɪn (sɑ-ɪ-din): si tʃɹu sɔɹs.

saidar (sah-ih-DAHR): saidin (sah-ih-DEEN): See True Source.

sɑldɑiə (sɑl-deɪ-i-ɑ): wʌn ə ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz.

Saldaea (sahl-DAY-ee-ah): One of the Borderlands.

sɑntʃ, sɪuən (sæn-tʃeɪ, swɑn): ən ɛɛs sədaɪ fɔɹmɝli ʌv ðə blu ədʒɑ. ɹeɪz tə ði æmɪɝlɪn sit naɪnhʌnʒɹədeɪtieɪt ni. ði æmɪɝlɪn siɾ ɪz ʌv ɔl ədʒəz, ən ə nʌn.

Sanche, Siuan (SAHN-chay, swahn): An Aes Sedai formerly of the Blue Ajah. Raised to the Amyrlin Seat 988 NE. The Amyrlin Seat is of all Ajahs, and of none.

si foʊk: mɔɹ pɹɑpɝli, ði æθɑn maɪɹ (ə-θɑ-æn mi-ɛɹ), ðə pipəl ə ðə si. ɪnhæbəɾənts ʌv aɪlənz ɪn ði ɛɹɪθ (ɑ-ɹɪθ) oʊʃən ən ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz, ðeɪ spɛn lɪɾəl taɪm ɑn ðoʊz aɪlənz, lɪvɪŋ moʊst ə ðɛɹ laɪvz ɑn ðɛɹ ʃɪps. moʊst sibɔɹn tʃɹeɪɾ ɪz kæɹid baɪ ðə si foʊks ʃɪps.

Sea Folk: More properly, the Atha'an Miere (a-tha-AHN mee-AIR), the People of the Sea. Inhabitants of islands in the Aryth (AH-rihth) Ocean and the Sea of Storms, they spend little time on those islands, living most of their lives on their ships. Most seaborne trade is carried by the Sea Folk's ships.

sintʃæn (ʃɔn-tʃæn): (wʌn) dɪsɛndəns ə ði ɑɹmiz ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ sɛn əkɹɔs ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən, hu hæv ɹɪtɝn tə ɹikleɪm ðə lænz ə ðɛɹ fɔɹfɑðɝz. (tu) ðə læn fɹəm wɪtʃ ðə sintʃæn kʌm. si ɔlsoʊ heɪlin; kɔɝɪn; ɹaɪædʒɛl.

Seanchan (SHAWN-CHAN): (1) Descendants of the armies Artur Hawkwing sent across the Aryth Ocean, who have returned to reclaim the lands of their forefathers. (2) The land from which the Seanchan come. See also Hailene; Corenne; Rhyagelle.

sindɑɹ (ʃɔn-dɑɹ): kæpəɾəl sɪɾi ʌv sintʃæn, wɛɹ ði ɛmpɹɛs sɪts ɑn ðə kɹɪstəl θɹoʊn ɪn ðə kɔɹɾ ə ðə naɪn munz.

Seandar (shawn-DAHR): Capital city of Seanchan, where the Empress sits on the Crystal Throne in the Court of the Nine Moons.

səlin (sɛ-lin): ə wʊmən mɛɾ ɑn ðə dʒɝni tə kɛɹhin.

Selene (seh-LEEN): A woman met on the journey to Cairhien.

sɛɾə (si-tɑ): eɪ sintʃæn wʊmən; ə sʌldəm. si ɔlsoʊ sintʃæn; sʌldəm.

Seta (SEE-tah): A Seanchan woman; a sul'dam. See also Seanchan; sul'dam.

ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ (ʃɑ-dɑɹ loʊ-ɡɑθ): ə sɪɾi əbændən ən ʃʌn sɪns ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz. ɪts teɪntɪd ɡɹaʊnd, ən nɑɾ ə pɛbəl ʌv ɪts seɪf. si ɔlsoʊ mɔɹɾɪθ.

Shadar Logoth (SHAH-dahr LOH-goth): A city abandoned and shunned since the Trolloc Wars. It is tainted ground, and not a pebble of it is safe. See also Mordeth.

ʃeɪtɑn (ʃeɪ-ɪ-tæn): si dɑɹk wʌn.

Shai'tan (SHAY-ih-TAN): See Dark One.

ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl (ʃeɪ-əl ɡul): ə maʊntən ɪn ðə blæstəd lænz, ðə saɪɾ ə ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən.

Shayol Ghul (SHAY-ol GHOOL): A mountain in the Blasted Lands, the site of the Dark One's prison.

ʃɛɹiəm (ʃɪɹ-i-ɑm): ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌv ðə blu ədʒɑ. ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ.

Sheriam (SHEER-ee-ahm): An Aes Sedai of the Blue Ajah. The Mistress of Novices in the White Tower.

ʃaɪnɝ (ʃaɪ-nɑɹ): wʌn ə ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz. ðə saɪn ə ʃaɪnɝ ɪz ə stupɪŋ blæk hɔk.

Shienar (shy-NAHR): One of the Borderlands. The sign of Shienar is a stooping black hawk.

ʃoʊufə (ʃu-fɑ): ə ɡɑɹmən ə ði il, ə klɔθ, juʒəwəli ðə kʌlɝ ə sæn əɹ ɹɑk, ðət ɹæps ɝaʊn ðə hɛɾ ən nɛk, livɪŋ oʊnli ðə feɪs bɛɹ.

shoufa (SHOO-fah): A garment of the Aiel, a cloth, usually the color of sand or rock, that wraps around the head and neck, leaving only the face bare.

spæn: si lɛŋθ, junəts ʌv.

span: See Length, units of.

spaɪn ə ðə wɝld, ðə: ə taʊɝɪŋ maʊntən ɹeɪnʒ, wɪð oʊnli ə fju pæsəz, wɪtʃ sɛpɝeɪts ði il weɪs fɹəm ðə lænz tə ðə wɛst.

Spine of the World, the: A towering mountain range, with only a few passes, which separates the Aiel Waste from the lands to the west.

stɛɾɪŋ (stɛd-dɪŋ): ən oʊɡiɝ (oʊhaɪoʊ-ɡɪɹ) hoʊmlænd. mɛni stɛɾɪŋ əv bɪn əbændən sɪns ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld. ðeɪ ɑɹ ʃildɪɾ ɪn səm weɪ, noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ʌndɝstʊd, soʊ ðət wɪðɪn əm noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ kən tʃænəl ðə wʌn paʊɝ, nɔɹ ivən sɛns ðət ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs ɪɡzɪsts. ətɛmps tə wil ðə wʌn paʊɝ fɹəm aʊtsaɪɾ ə stɛɾɪŋ əv noʊ ɪfɛkt ɪnsaɪɾ ə stɛɾɪŋ baʊndɝi. noʊ tʃɹɑlɑk wɪl ɛntɝ ə stɛɾɪŋ ənlɛs dʒɹɪvən, ən ivən ə mɹdʒɹɑl wɪl də soʊ oʊnli ət ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst niɾ ən ðən wɪð ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst ɹɪlʌktəns ən dɪsteɪst. ivən dɑɹkfɹɛnz, ɪf tʃɹuli dɛɾəkeɪtəd, fil ənkʌmftəɹbəl wɪðɪn ə stɛɾɪŋ.

stedding (STEHD-ding): An Ogier (OH-geer) homeland. Many stedding have been abandoned since the Breaking of the World. They are shielded in some way, no longer understood, so that within them no Aes Sedai can channel the One Power, nor even sense that the True Source exists. Attempts to wield the One Power from outside a stedding have no effect inside a stedding boundary. No Trolloc will enter a stedding unless driven, and even a Myrddraal will do so only at the greatest need and then with the greatest reluctance and distaste. Even Darkfriends, if truly dedicated, feel uncomfortable within a stedding.

stɪlɪŋ: ði ækt, pɝfɔɹm baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ʌv ʃʌɾɪŋ ɔf ə wʊmən u kən tʃænəl fɹəm ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ə wʊmən u hæz bɪn stɪl kən sɛns ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs, bʌt ʃi kænɑt tʌtʃ ɪt. si ɔlsoʊ wʌn paʊɝ, ðə; dʒɛntəlɪŋ.

stilling: the act, performed by Aes Sedai, of shutting off a woman who can channel from the One Power. A woman who has been stilled can sense the True Source, but she cannot touch it. See also One Power, the; gentling.

stoʊn dɑɡz: si il wɔɹiɝ səsaɪəɾiz.

Stone Dogs: See Aiel warrior societies.

sʌldəm (sul-dæm): ə wʊmən u hæz pæs ðə tɛsts tə ʃoʊ ðət ʃi kən wɛɹ ðə bɹeɪsləɾ ʌv ən æɾəm ən ðʌs kəntʃɹoʊl ə deɪmeɪn. si ɔlsoʊ æɾəm; deɪmeɪn.

sul'dam (SUHL-DAHM): A woman who has passed the tests to show that she can wear the bracelet of an a'dam and thus control a damane. See also a'dam; damane.

sʌndeɪ: ə fistdeɪ ən fɛstəvəl ɪn mɪdsʌmɝ, sɛləbɹeɪɾəd ɪn mɛni pɑɹts ə ðə wɝld.

Sunday: A feastday and festival in midsummer, celebrated in many parts of the world.

sʌŋ wʊd: si tʃɹisɪŋʒɝ.

sung wood: See Treesinger.

sjuɹɔθ, haɪ leɪɾi (su-ɹɔθ): eɪ sintʃæn noʊbəlwʊmən ə haɪ dɪɡɹi.

Suroth, High Lady (SUE-roth): A Seanchan noblewoman of high degree.

teɪʃɝ (taɪ-ʃɑɹ): ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "tʃɹu blʌɾ ʌv."

Tai'shar (TIE-SHAHR): In the Old Tongue, "True blood of."

tæmɹəleɪlən (tɑ-mɑɹ-ɑl-aɪ-lɛn): ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "wɛb ə dɛstəni." ə ɡɹeɪt tʃeɪnʒ ɪn ðə pæɾɝn ʌv ən eɪdʒ, sɛntɝɾ ɝaʊnd wʌn əɹ mɔɹ pipəl u ɑɹ tɑvɝən. si ɔlsoʊ pæɾɝn ʌv ən eɪdʒ; tɑvɝən.

ta'maral'ailen (tah-MAHR-ahl-EYE-lehn): In the Old Tongue, "Web of Destiny." A great change in the Pattern of an Age, centered around one or more people who are ta'veren. See also Pattern of an Age; ta'veren.

tænɹəl, ɑɹɾɝ pɛndʒɹæɡ (tæn-ɹi-ɑl, ɑɹ-tʃɹ peɪ-ɛn-dʒɹæɡ): si hɔkwɪŋ, ɑɹɾɝ.

Tanreall, Artur Paendrag (tahn-REE-ahl, AHR-tuhr PAY-ehn-DRAG): See Hawkwing, Artur.

tɑɹmən ɡdən (tɑɹ-mɑn ɡeɪ-dɑn): ðə læs bæɾəl. si ɔlsoʊ dʒɹæɡən, pɹɑfəsiz ə ðə; hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ.

Tarmon Gai'don (TAHR-mohn GAY-dohn): The Last Battle. See also Dragon, Prophecies of the; Horn of Valere.

tɑɹ vəlɑn (tɑɹ vɑ-lɑn): ə sɪɾi ɑn ən aɪlən ɪn ðə ɹɪvɝ ɛɹɪnɪn. ðə sɛntɝ ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ paʊɝ, ən loʊkeɪʃən ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ.

Tar Valon (TAHR VAH-lon): A city on an island in the River Erinin. The center of Aes Sedai power, and location of the White Tower.

tɑvɝən (tɑ-vɪɹ-ɛn): ə pɝsən ɝaʊn hum ðə wil ə taɪm wivz ɔl sɝaʊndɪŋ laɪf-θɹɛdz, pɝhæps ɔl laɪf-θɹɛdz, tə fɔɹm ə wɛb ə dɛstəni. si ɔlsoʊ pæɾɝn ʌv ən eɪdʒ.

ta'veren (tah-VEER-ehn): A person around whom the Wheel of Time weaves all surrounding life-threads, perhaps all life-threads, to form a Web of Destiny. See also Pattern of an Age.

tɛɹ (tɪɹ): ə ɡɹeɪt sipɔɹɾ ɑn ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz.

Tear (TEER): A great seaport on the Sea of Storms.

tɛləmən, luz θɝɪn (tɛl-ɑ-moʊn, luz θɛ-ɹɪn): si dʒɹæɡən, ðə.

Telamon, Lews Therin (TEHL-ah-mon, LOOZ THEH-rihn): See Dragon, the.

tɛɹæŋɡɹil (tɪɹ-æn-ɡɹi-ɑl): ɛni wʌn ʌv ə nʌmbɝ ə ɹɛmnəns ə ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz ðət juz ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ənlaɪk æŋɡɹil ən sɑŋɡɹil, itʃ tɛɹæŋɡɹil wɑz meɪd tə də ə pɝtɪkjəlɝ θɪŋ. fəɹ ɪɡzæmpəl, wʌn meɪks oʊðz teɪkən wɪðɪn ɪt baɪndɪŋ. səm ɑɹ juz baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌt ðɛɹ ɝɪdʒənəl pɝpəsəz ɑɹ lɑɹdʒli ənnoʊn. səm wɪl kɪl əɹ dɪstʃɹɔɪ ði əbɪləɾi tə tʃænəl ʌv ɛni wʊmən u juzɪz ðɛm. si ɔlsoʊ æŋɡɹil; sɑŋɡɹil.

ter'angreal (TEER-ahn-GREE-ahl): Any one of a number of remnants of the Age of Legends that use the One Power. Unlike angreal and sa'angreal, each ter'angreal was made to do a particular thing. For example, one makes oaths taken within it binding. Some are used by Aes Sedai, but their original purposes are largely unknown. Some will kill or destroy the ability to channel of any woman who uses them. See also angreal; sa'angreal.

tiə ɑvɛn ælɑntɪn (ti-ɑ ɑ-vɛn-deɪ ɑ-læn-tɪn): "bɹʌðɝ tə ðə tʃɹiz."

tia avende alantin (TEE-ah ah-VEN-day ah-LANH-tin): "Brother to the Trees."

tiə mi ɑveɪən mɔɹaɪɾɪn ɪeɪn veɪɾɪn: ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "ðə ɡɹeɪv ɪz noʊ bɑɹ tə maɪ kɔl." ɪnskɹɪpʃən ɑn ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ. si ɔlsoʊ hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ.

Tia mi aven Moridin isainde vadin: In the Old Tongue, "The grave is no bar to my call." Inscription on the Horn of Valere. See also Horn of Valere.

tɪɡɹeɪn (ti-ɡɹeɪn): əz dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ʌv ændɝ, ʃi mɛɹid tɑɹɪŋɡeɪl dəmədʒɹɾ ən bɔɹ ɪz sʌn ɡɑleɪdɛdʒɹəd. hɝ dɪsəpɪɹəns ɪn naɪnhʌnʒɹədsɛvəntitu ni, ʃɔɹtli æftɝ əɹ bɹʌðɝ luk vænɪʃt ɪn ðə blaɪt, lɛd tə ðə stʃɹʌɡəl ɪn ændɝ kɔl ðə səksɛʃən, ən kɑz ði ɪvɛns ɪn kɛɹhin ðəɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli bɹɔɾ ɑn ði il wɔɹ. hɝ saɪn wɑz ə wʊmənz hænd ɡɹɪpɪŋ ə θɔɹni ɹoʊz stɛm wɪð ə waɪt blɑsəm.

Tigraine (tee-GRAIN): As Daughter-Heir of Andor, she married Taringail Damodred and bore his son Galadedrid. Her disappearance in 972 NE, shortly after her brother Luc vanished in the Blight, led to the struggle in Andor called the Succession, and caused the events in Cairhien that eventually brought on the Aiel War. Her sign was a woman's hand gripping a thorny rose stem with a white blossom.

taɪm ə mædnəs: ðə jɪɹz æftɝ ðə dɑɹk wʌnz kaʊntɝstʃɹoʊk teɪntɪd ðə meɪl hæf ə ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs, wən meɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ wɛn mæɾ ən bɹoʊk ðə wɝld. ði ɪɡzæk dʊɹeɪʃən ə ðɪs pɪɹiəɾ ɪz ənnoʊn, bʌɾ ɪts bɪliv tə hæv læstəd nɪɹli wʌn hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz. ɪɾ ɛndəd kəmplitli oʊnli wɪð ðə dɛθ ə ðə læs meɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ. si ɔlsoʊ hʌnʒɹəd kəmpænjənz; tʃɹu sɔɹs; wʌn paʊɝ; bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld.

Time of Madness: The years after the Dark One's counterstroke tainted the male half of the True Source, when male Aes Sedai went mad and Broke the World. The exact duration of this period is unknown, but it is believed to have lasted nearly one hundred years. It ended completely only with the death of the last male Aes Sedai. See also Hundred Companions; True Source; One Power; Breaking of the World.

tɪŋkɝz: si tuætɑn.

Tinkers: See Tuatha'an.

tʃɹævlɪŋ pipəl: si tuætɑn.

Traveling People: See Tuatha'an.

tʃɹi, ðə: si ɑvɛndɪsɔɹə.

Tree, the: See Avendesora.

tʃɹikɪlɝz: ən il neɪm fəɹ ðə kɛɹhinɪn, ɔlweɪz sɛɾ ɪn toʊnz ə hɔɹɝ ən dɪsɡʌst.

Treekillers: An Aiel name for the Cairhienin, always said in tones of horror and disgust.

tʃɹisɪŋʒɝ: ən oʊɡiɝ u hæz ði əbɪləɾi tə sɪŋ tə tʃɹiz (kɔld "tʃɹisɔŋ"), iðɝ hilɪŋ ðɛm, əɹ hɛlpɪŋ əm tə ɡɹoʊ ən flaʊɝ, əɹ meɪkɪŋ θɪŋz fɹəm ðə wʊd wɪθaʊt dæmɪdʒɪŋ ðə tʃɹi. ɑbʒɛkts meɪɾ ɪn ðɪs mænɝ ɑɹ kɔld "sʌŋ wʊd" ən ɑɹ haɪli pɹaɪzd. fju oʊɡiɝ ɹɪmeɪn u ɑɹ tʃɹisɪŋɝz; ðə tælən simz tə bi daɪɪŋ aʊt.

Treesinger: An Ogier who has the ability to sing to trees (called "treesong"), either healing them, or helping them to grow and flower, or making things from the wood without damaging the tree. Objects made in this manner are called "sung wood" and are highly prized. Few Ogier remain who are Treesingers; the Talent seems to be dying out.

tʃɹisɔŋ: si tʃɹisɪŋʒɝ.

treesong: See Treesinger.

tʃɹɑləks (tʃɹæl-loʊks): kɹitʃɝz ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn, kɹieɪɾəd dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ. hjudʒ ɪn stætʃɝ, ðeɪ ɑɹ ə twɪstəd blɛn ʌv ænəməl ən hjumən stɑk. vɪʃəs baɪ neɪtʃɝ, ðeɪ kɪl fəɹ ðə pjʊɹ plɛʒɝ ə kɪlɪŋ. dəsitfəl ɪn ði ɪkstʃɹim, ðeɪ kænɑt bi tʃɹʌstɪɾ ənlɛs koʊɝs baɪ fɪɹ. ðeɪ ɑɹ dɪvaɪɾəd ɪndə tʃɹaɪb-laɪk bænz, əmʌŋ əm ðə dɑvɑl, ðə koʊbəl, ən ðə deɪmən.

Trollocs (TRAHL-lohks): Creatures of the Dark One, created during the War of the Shadow. Huge in stature, they are a twisted blend of animal and human stock. Vicious by nature, they kill for the pure pleasure of killing. Deceitful in the extreme, they cannot be trusted unless coerced by fear. They are divided into tribe-like bands, among them the Dha'vol, the Ko'bal, and the Dhai'mon.

tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz: ə sɪɹiz ʌv wɔɹz, bɪɡɪnɪŋ əbaʊt wʌnθaʊzən æb ən læstɪŋ mɔɹ ðən θɹi hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz, dʊɹɪŋ wɪtʃ tʃɹɑlɑk ɑɹmiz ɹævɪdʒ ðə wɝld. ɪvɛntʃəwəli ðə tʃɹɑləks wɝ sleɪn əɹ dʒɹɪvən bæk ɪndə ðə ɡɹeɪt blaɪt, bʌt səm neɪʃənz sis tə ɪɡzɪst, waɪl ʌðɝz wɝ ɔlmoʊs dɪpɑpjəleɪɾɪd. ɔl ɹɛkɝdz ə ðə taɪm ɑɹ fɹæɡməntɛɹi. si ɔlsoʊ kʌvənən ə ðə tɛn neɪʃənz.

Trolloc Wars: A series of wars, beginning about 1000 AB and lasting more than three hundred years, during which Trolloc armies ravaged the world. Eventually the Trollocs were slain or driven back into the Great Blight, but some nations ceased to exist, while others were almost depopulated. All records of the time are fragmentary. See also Covenant of the Ten Nations.

tʃɹu sɔɹs: ðə dʒɹaɪvɪŋ fɔɹs ə ðə junəvɝs, wɪtʃ tɝnz ðə wil ə taɪm. ɪts dɪvaɪɾəd ɪndə ə meɪl hæf (seɪɾɪn) ən ə fimeɪl hæf (seɪaɪdɑɹ), wɪtʃ wɝk ət ðə seɪm taɪm wɪð ən əɡɛnst itʃ ʌðɝ. oʊnli ə mæn kən dʒɹɔ ɑn seɪɾɪn, oʊnli ə wʊmən ɑn seɪaɪdɑɹ. sɪns ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ ə ðə taɪm ə mædnəs, seɪɾɪn əz bɪn teɪntɪd baɪ ðə dɑɹk wʌnz tʌtʃ. si ɔlsoʊ wʌn paʊɝ.

True Source: The driving force of the universe, which turns the Wheel of Time.
